speaker: Ada Chen Rekhi
speaker_expertise: Executive Coaching, Career Development, Leadership Development
text: And it's not bad because it's not well-intentioned, but it's bad because it's not contextual. So when someone tells you to quit your job and chase your dreams, or they tell you to sit tight and grind through and build some experience before you go off and go start the company that you've always been thinking about starting, which piece of advice do you actually take? A lot of it depends on your situation, what you're considering, what skills and experience you actually have, and curiosity loops actually are this way of really thinking about how do you make your advice contextual.
text_ko: 그게 나쁜 이유는 잘못된 의도 때문이 아니라, 상황에 맞지 않기 때문이에요. 그래서 누군가가 당신에게 직장을 그만두고 꿈을 쫓으라고 하거나, 아니면 조금 더 버티면서 경험을 쌓으라고 할 때, 어떤 조언을 실제로 받아들여야 할까요? 이건 정말 당신의 상황, 고민하고 있는 것, 가지고 있는 기술과 경험에 따라 달라져요. 그리고 호기심 루프(curiosity loop)는 조언을 어떻게 상황에 맞게 만들 수 있을지를 생각하는 좋은 방법이에요.
text_zh: 这并不是因为建议出发点不善良而糟糕，而是因为缺乏具体情境。因此，当有人告诉你辞掉工作去追求梦想，或者让你耐心坚持，积累经验再去创办你一直想创办的公司时，你究竟该听取哪种建议呢？很多时候，这取决于你的具体情况、你正在考虑的事项、你实际拥有的技能和经验。而“好奇循环”（curiosity loops）正是一种思考如何使建议具有情境性的方式。
text_es: Y no está mal porque no sea bien intencionado, sino que está mal porque no es contextual. Así que cuando alguien te dice que dejes tu trabajo y persigas tus sueños, o te aconseja que te mantengas firme y trabajes duro para adquirir experiencia antes de lanzarte a crear la empresa que siempre has querido iniciar, ¿cuál de esos consejos realmente sigues? Mucho depende de tu situación, de lo que estás considerando, de las habilidades y la experiencia que realmente tienes, y los bucles de curiosidad (curiosity loops) son una forma de pensar en cómo hacer que tu consejo sea contextual.
context: Lenny asks Ada to explain curiosity loops after she used this method to gather structured feedback for their podcast conversation. A curiosity loop is when you ask the same question to multiple people (around 10-15) to gather diverse perspectives rather than relying on one person's opinion. Ada explains that most advice fails not because of bad intentions, but because it lacks context for your specific situation - what worked for one person may not apply to your circumstances.
vocabulary_highlights: well-intentioned, contextual, sit tight and grind through, curiosity loops

speaker: Ada Chen Rekhi
speaker_expertise: Executive Coaching, Career Development, Leadership Development
text: One thing was really telling, no one out of everyone we asked said 18. So that really dragged my partner up. And then the other thing that was really interesting was that we learned a little bit about executive function and the research around it. So executive function, which is your ability to make decisions and plans and be thoughtful peaks at the age of 30, and it's all downhill from there.
text_ko: 한 가지 정말 흥미로운 점은 우리가 물어본 사람들 중에 아무도 18이라고 답하지 않았다는 거예요. 그래서 그게 제 파트너에게 큰 영향을 줬어요. 그리고 또 하나 재미있었던 건, 우리는 실행 기능(executive function)과 그에 대한 연구에 대해 조금 배웠다는 거예요. 실행 기능은 결정을 내리고 계획을 세우고 사려 깊게 행동하는 능력인데, 이게 30세에 최고조에 이르고 그 이후로는 점점 떨어진다고 하더라고요.
text_zh: 有一点非常明显，我们问的所有人中没有一个人提到18岁。这让我的合伙人感到很震惊。另外一个有趣的发现是，我们了解到了一些关于执行功能（executive function）及其相关研究的信息。执行功能是指你做决策、制定计划和深思熟虑的能力，这种能力在30岁时达到巅峰，之后就开始下降。
text_es: Una cosa que fue muy reveladora fue que nadie de todos a quienes preguntamos mencionó 18. Eso realmente sorprendió a mi socio. Y lo otro que fue muy interesante es que aprendimos un poco sobre la función ejecutiva y la investigación relacionada. La función ejecutiva, que es tu capacidad para tomar decisiones y hacer planes de manera reflexiva, alcanza su punto máximo a los 30 años, y a partir de ahí comienza a decaer.
context: Ada gives a personal example of using curiosity loops for non-work decisions. She and her partner were debating when their daughter should inherit their estate if something happened to both parents - he wanted 18 years old, she wanted 25. They asked trusted friends and family for input, discovering unanimous feedback against 18 and learning about executive function research that informed their final decision.
vocabulary_highlights: really telling, dragged my partner up, executive function, it's all downhill from there

speaker: Ada Chen Rekhi
speaker_expertise: Executive Coaching, Career Development, Leadership Development
text: When I reflect back on what works across my early career, it really comes down in a nutshell to this career concept of explore and exploit. You're either in a mode of explorer where you have a bunch of unknowns and you're testing to see whether or not you like it, or you're exploiting, where you actually have found something that's really rich and really deep.
text_ko: 내 경력을 돌아보면, 결국에는 '탐색(explore)과 활용(exploit)'이라는 경력 개념으로 요약할 수 있어요. 탐색하는 모드에 있을 때는 여러 가지 미지의 것들을 경험해보면서 내가 좋아하는지 테스트하는 단계고, 활용하는 모드에 들어가면 정말 가치 있고 깊이 있는 것을 찾은 상태예요.
text_zh: 回顾我早期职业生涯中有效的经验，归根结底可以总结为“探索与利用”（explore and exploit）的职业理念。你要么处于探索者的状态，面对许多未知的事物，测试自己是否喜欢；要么处于利用的状态，发现了一些真正丰富且深刻的机会。
text_es: Cuando reflexiono sobre lo que ha funcionado en mi carrera temprana, se reduce a este concepto profesional de explorar y explotar. Estás en un modo de explorador, donde hay muchas incógnitas y estás probando para ver si te gusta, o estás en modo de explotación, donde realmente has encontrado algo que es muy valioso y profundo.
context: Lenny asks Ada about her advice for early career professionals, noting her rapid career progression from entry-level at Microsoft to SVP of marketing at SurveyMonkey in seven years. Ada explains her framework of 'explore and exploit' - early in your career you should explore different roles and industries to find what you enjoy, then once you find something valuable, exploit it by going deep and building expertise in that area.
vocabulary_highlights: in a nutshell, mode of explorer, bunch of unknowns, really rich and really deep

speaker: Ada Chen Rekhi
speaker_expertise: Executive Coaching, Career Development, Leadership Development
text: It's really easy to be a victim of inertia. It's really easy for all of us to be the frog where there are little things that make us uncomfortable, and we sit with them or we think, 'Gosh, it'll get better. The next manager will get better. I'm always one conversation or one promotion away from getting to that next step.' But you really have to be aware of your surroundings. You have to be aware of which way is the direction of the temperature of the water trending.
text_ko: 관성의 희생자가 되는 건 정말 쉽죠. 우리 모두가 불편한 작은 것들에 대해 그냥 앉아 있거나 '아, 다음 매니저가 더 나아질 거야. 나는 항상 한 번의 대화나 승진만 있으면 다음 단계에 도달할 수 있어.'라고 생각하는 개구리가 되기 쉬워요. 하지만 주변을 잘 살펴봐야 해요. 물의 온도가 어떤 방향으로 가고 있는지 인식하는 게 중요해요.
text_zh: 很容易成为惯性的受害者。我们每个人都可能像那只青蛙一样，面对一些让我们不舒服的小事，却选择忍耐，心里想着“哦，这会好起来的，下一个经理会更好。我总是离下一步的对话或晋升只有一步之遥。”但你真的需要关注周围的环境，留意水温的变化方向。
text_es: Es muy fácil caer en la inercia. Todos podemos ser como la rana que se siente incómoda con pequeñas cosas, y nos quedamos ahí pensando: "Bueno, esto mejorará. El próximo gerente será mejor. Siempre estoy a una conversación o a una promoción de dar el siguiente paso." Pero realmente debes estar consciente de tu entorno. Debes estar atento a hacia dónde se está moviendo la temperatura del agua.
context: Lenny asks Ada how to know when to stick with a difficult job that might lead somewhere versus when to leave. Ada uses the metaphor of a frog being slowly boiled alive - if you put a frog in boiling water it jumps out, but if you gradually increase the temperature it doesn't notice until it's too late. She explains this applies to career situations where people become victims of inertia, always thinking things will improve with the next manager or promotion.
vocabulary_highlights: victim of inertia, be the frog, one conversation or one promotion away, temperature of the water trending

speaker: Ada Chen Rekhi
speaker_expertise: Executive Coaching, Career Development, Leadership Development
text: I think that's a terrible trap that we should all try to avoid as we navigate our career paths and find the thing that's most optimal for us. Which is usually a mix of career success, but also meaningfulness and alignment in the work that we're doing with our values.
text_ko: 우리는 경력 경로를 탐색하면서 피해야 할 끔찍한 함정이라고 생각해요. 우리에게 가장 최적화된 것을 찾는 과정에서 말이죠. 보통은 경력 성공의 조합이지만, 우리가 하는 일에서 의미와 가치와의 일치도 중요하잖아요.
text_zh: 我认为这是一个我们都应该尽量避免的陷阱，在我们职业发展和寻找最适合自己的方向时，通常需要平衡职业成功、工作意义以及与我们价值观的契合。
text_es: Creo que es una trampa terrible que todos debemos intentar evitar mientras navegamos por nuestras trayectorias profesionales y encontramos lo que es más óptimo para nosotros. Lo cual, por lo general, es una combinación de éxito profesional, pero también de significado y alineación en el trabajo que realizamos con nuestros valores.
context: Ada is discussing the importance of not getting trapped in a career path driven solely by external expectations or lifestyle requirements. She emphasizes that waking up late in your career feeling unhappy with your work, but unable to change due to financial obligations or others' expectations, is a terrible outcome. She advocates for finding work that balances career success with personal meaningfulness and alignment with your core values.
vocabulary_highlights: terrible trap, navigate our career paths, most optimal for us, meaningfulness and alignment

speaker: Ada Chen Rekhi
speaker_expertise: Executive Coaching, Career Development, Leadership Development
text: My hot take is that for the vast majority of people, they probably do not need a coach. And what I often push people on is if you're thinking about getting a coach, which is usually an indication that they have a feeling of being stuck or they have a problem that they're trying to solve, I ask them, 'What are your goals when it comes to coaching?'
text_ko: 내 생각에는 대다수의 사람들에게 코치가 꼭 필요하지는 않은 것 같아요. 보통 사람들이 코치를 생각할 때는 뭔가 막히거나 해결하고 싶은 문제가 있다는 신호거든요. 그래서 저는 그들에게 "코칭을 통해 어떤 목표를 이루고 싶으세요?"라고 물어봐요.
text_zh: 我的看法是，对于绝大多数人来说，他们可能并不需要教练（coach）。我常常会问那些考虑请教练的人，因为这通常表明他们感到困惑或有问题需要解决，我会问他们：“你在教练方面的目标是什么？”
text_es: Mi opinión es que para la gran mayoría de las personas, probablemente no necesitan un coach. Y lo que a menudo les pregunto es que si están considerando contratar a un coach, lo cual generalmente indica que se sienten estancados o tienen un problema que intentan resolver, les pregunto: '¿Cuáles son tus objetivos en relación al coaching?'
context: Lenny asks Ada about when people should consider getting an executive coach, given her work as a coach to founders. Surprisingly, Ada argues that most people don't actually need a coach and should first explore alternatives like mentorship through curiosity loops, taking courses, or building supportive communities. She challenges people to clearly define their coaching goals and consider if there are better ways to achieve those same outcomes.
vocabulary_highlights: hot take, push people on, indication that they have a feeling, being stuck

speaker: Adam Fishman
speaker_expertise: Product Management, B2B SaaS, Product Strategy
text: Onboarding is the only part of your product experience that a hundred percent of people are ever going to touch. Good luck getting a hundred percent feature adoption of anything else in your product, right? But onboarding is the thing that you have to go through in order to use the product. It's also the first opportunity that you have as a company to deliver on the promise that you made out in the marketplace.
text_ko: 온보딩(onboarding)은 여러분의 제품 경험 중에서 모든 사람들이 반드시 경험하게 되는 유일한 부분이에요. 다른 어떤 기능도 100% 사용자가 다 사용할 거라고 기대하기는 힘들죠. 하지만 온보딩은 제품을 사용하기 위해 반드시 거쳐야 하는 과정이에요. 그리고 이건 여러분이 시장에서 약속한 것을 실현할 수 있는 첫 번째 기회이기도 해요.
text_zh: 用户引导是您产品体验中唯一一个百分之百的用户都会接触到的部分。想要实现其他功能的百分之百采用率几乎是不可能的，对吧？但是用户引导是用户使用产品之前必须经历的过程。这也是您作为公司在市场上兑现承诺的第一次机会。
text_es: La incorporación (onboarding) es la única parte de la experiencia de tu producto que el cien por ciento de las personas va a experimentar. Buena suerte logrando que el cien por ciento adopte cualquier otra función en tu producto, ¿verdad? Pero la incorporación es el proceso que todos deben atravesar para poder utilizar el producto. También es la primera oportunidad que tienes como empresa para cumplir con la promesa que hiciste en el mercado.
context: Lenny asks Adam about onboarding as a growth lever and what gets him excited about investing in onboarding optimization. Adam explains why onboarding is such a critical part of the product experience that companies should prioritize. He emphasizes that onboarding is unique because it's the only feature with 100% user adoption, and it's the first chance to deliver on your brand promise to customers.
vocabulary_highlights: deliver on the promise, out in the marketplace

speaker: Adam Fishman
speaker_expertise: Product Management, B2B SaaS, Product Strategy
text: I like to think of your brand is the promise that you're making and your product experience is your delivery of that promise. And those two things have to be in lockstep with each other, or you're going to have mismatched expectations and some really disappointed customers. So this is the first chance that a customer has to be really excited or really disappointed in what they thought they were getting. So don't mess that up.
text_ko: 당신의 브랜드는 약속이라고 생각해요. 그리고 제품 경험은 그 약속을 실현하는 방식이죠. 이 두 가지는 항상 맞물려 있어야 해요. 그렇지 않으면 고객의 기대와 실제 경험이 다르게 되어 실망하는 경우가 생길 수 있어요. 고객이 처음으로 느끼는 감정이 정말 기대되거나 실망스러울 수 있으니까, 이 부분을 잘 챙겨야 해요. 실수하지 마세요.
text_zh: 我认为你的品牌是你所做的承诺，而你的产品体验则是对这个承诺的兑现。这两者必须紧密相连，否则就会导致期望不匹配，进而让客户感到失望。因此，这是客户第一次真正感受到兴奋或失望的机会，所以一定要把握好这个环节。
text_es: Me gusta pensar en tu marca como la promesa que estás haciendo, y la experiencia de tu producto como la entrega de esa promesa. Ambas deben estar alineadas, de lo contrario, tendrás expectativas desajustadas y clientes realmente decepcionados. Esta es la primera oportunidad que tiene un cliente para sentirse realmente emocionado o muy decepcionado con lo que pensaba que iba a recibir. Así que no lo estropees.
context: Adam continues explaining why onboarding is such a crucial growth lever for companies. He describes the relationship between brand promises and product delivery, emphasizing that these must be perfectly aligned. Adam warns that onboarding is the critical moment where customers first experience whether the product matches their expectations from marketing and sales efforts.
vocabulary_highlights: in lockstep with each other, mismatched expectations, don't mess that up

speaker: Adam Fishman
speaker_expertise: Product Management, B2B SaaS, Product Strategy
text: The goal of the competency model is not to find a unicorn human being that is an 11 out of 10 on every one of these things, because frankly, that person doesn't exist. I am not an 11 out of 10 on these skills and I have been a growth executive at many companies. I consider myself to be pretty good at the job. The goal is to create a well-rounded team so that you're hiring and balancing skills across your team and that you don't have any gaps in your portfolio.
text_ko: 역량 모델의 목표는 모든 항목에서 10점 만점에 11점을 주는 유니콘 같은 사람을 찾는 게 아니에요. 솔직히 그런 사람은 존재하지 않거든요. 저도 이 스킬들에서 10점 만점에 11점은 아니지만, 여러 회사에서 성장 임원으로 일해왔어요. 제 일을 꽤 잘한다고 생각해요. 목표는 잘 균형 잡힌 팀을 만드는 거예요. 그래서 팀의 스킬을 다양하게 채용하고 포트폴리오에 빈틈이 없도록 하는 게 중요해요.
text_zh: 能力模型的目标并不是寻找一个在所有方面都能达到满分11分的“独角兽”人才，因为坦白说，这样的人并不存在。我在这些技能上也不是满分11分，但我在许多公司担任过增长高管，并且认为自己在这份工作上表现相当不错。目标是建立一个全面发展的团队，以便在招聘时能够平衡团队的技能，确保你的团队中没有技能空缺。
text_es: El objetivo del modelo de competencias no es encontrar un ser humano unicornio que sea un 11 de 10 en cada una de estas áreas, porque, francamente, esa persona no existe. Yo no soy un 11 de 10 en estas habilidades y he sido un ejecutivo de crecimiento en muchas empresas. Me considero bastante bueno en mi trabajo. El objetivo es crear un equipo equilibrado para que estés contratando y balanceando habilidades en tu equipo y así no tengas ninguna brecha en tu portafolio.
context: Lenny asks Adam about the components of his growth competency model for hiring growth professionals. Adam explains that the model isn't about finding perfect candidates who excel at everything, but rather about building balanced teams. He emphasizes that even experienced growth executives like himself aren't perfect at all skills, and the key is ensuring your team collectively covers all necessary competencies without gaps.
vocabulary_highlights: unicorn human being, 11 out of 10, well-rounded team, gaps in your portfolio

speaker: Adam Fishman
speaker_expertise: Product Management, B2B SaaS, Product Strategy
text: One of the challenges of hiring a senior person is that they're all off writing newsletters and making podcast. Not that we know anybody who does that or anything, but... So I don't want to right now go back and work at a company again. I'm enjoying what I'm doing and so it's hard to get me, right? But also you don't want me, I think, when you're doing this for the first time.
text_ko: 고위직 사람을 채용하는 데 어려운 점 중 하나는 그들이 모두 뉴스레터를 쓰고 팟캐스트를 만드는 데 바쁘다는 거예요. 그런 사람을 아는 건 아니지만... 지금은 다시 회사에서 일하고 싶지 않아요. 제가 하고 있는 일이 너무 재밌어서요. 그래서 저를 구하는 게 쉽지 않을 거예요, 맞죠? 하지만 처음 이걸 시도할 때는 저 같은 사람을 원하지 않을 것 같기도 해요.
text_zh: 招聘高级人才的一个挑战是，他们往往忙于撰写通讯和制作播客。并不是说我们认识这样的人，但……所以我现在不想回到公司工作。我很享受我现在的工作，因此很难找到我，对吧？但我觉得在你第一次进行这样的尝试时，你也不太需要我。
text_es: Uno de los desafíos de contratar a una persona senior es que todos están ocupados escribiendo boletines y haciendo podcasts. No es que conozcamos a alguien que haga eso, pero... Así que no quiero volver a trabajar en una empresa en este momento. Estoy disfrutando lo que hago y por eso es difícil que me consigan, ¿verdad? Pero también creo que no me querrían, especialmente si están haciendo esto por primera vez.
context: Lenny asks whether founders should focus on finding up-and-coming growth talent versus senior executives. Adam humorously points out that many senior growth professionals have moved into advisory roles or content creation, making them unavailable for full-time positions. He suggests that founders shouldn't necessarily want the most senior person anyway when building their first growth function.
vocabulary_highlights: off writing newsletters, hard to get me

speaker: Adam Fishman
speaker_expertise: Product Management, B2B SaaS, Product Strategy
text: So if you're going to hire a junior person, the key is, how do you help them learn? And I think if you don't know what you're doing as the founder or the leader, it's hard. You're not going to be able to help them yourself. So you've got to be willing to invest in advisors like me, outside education, mentorship, coaching, otherwise, what's going to happen is that very driven, hungry and enthusiastic person is going to run through a lot of brick walls, which is great, except they're going to miss the fact that the door was standing right next to the wall that they just ran through and you're going to end up with a lot of bricks on the ground.
text_ko: 주니어 직원을 채용할 거라면, 가장 중요한 건 그들이 어떻게 배우도록 도와줄 수 있을까 하는 거예요. 만약 창립자나 리더로서 내가 뭘 하고 있는지 모른다면, 그들을 도와주기가 힘들어요. 그러니까 저 같은 외부 전문가나 교육, 멘토링, 코칭에 투자할 준비가 되어 있어야 해요. 그렇지 않으면, 의욕 넘치고 열정적인 그 사람이 벽을 뚫고 나가게 될 텐데, 그건 좋지만, 사실 그 벽 옆에 문이 있었던 걸 놓치게 될 거예요. 결국 바닥에 많은 벽돌만 남게 될 거예요.
text_zh: 如果你打算招聘一位初级员工，关键在于如何帮助他们学习。我认为，如果作为创始人或领导者你自己都不清楚该怎么做，那就很困难。你无法亲自帮助他们。因此，你必须愿意投资于像我这样的顾问、外部教育、指导和教练。否则，结果就是那些充满干劲、渴望和热情的人会不断撞墙，这固然很好，但他们可能会忽视旁边就有一扇门，而最终你会发现地上满是砖头。
text_es: Si vas a contratar a una persona junior, la clave es cómo ayudarles a aprender. Y creo que si no sabes lo que estás haciendo como fundador o líder, es complicado. No podrás ayudarles tú mismo. Por lo tanto, debes estar dispuesto a invertir en asesores como yo, educación externa, mentoría, coaching; de lo contrario, lo que sucederá es que esa persona muy motivada, hambrienta y entusiasta va a chocar contra muchas paredes, lo cual está bien, excepto que van a pasar por alto el hecho de que la puerta estaba justo al lado de la pared por la que acaban de pasar y terminarás con muchos ladrillos en el suelo.
context: Adam continues discussing the strategy of hiring junior growth talent instead of senior executives. He explains that while hiring junior people can work well, founders need to invest in proper support systems like advisors, education, and mentorship. Adam uses a vivid metaphor to illustrate how enthusiastic but inexperienced people can waste effort on the wrong approaches when they lack proper guidance.
vocabulary_highlights: run through a lot of brick walls, standing right next to the wall, end up with a lot of bricks on the ground

speaker: Adam Fishman
speaker_expertise: Product Management, B2B SaaS, Product Strategy
text: I actually think if you're doing it right, sometimes conversion should actually decrease a little bit. So you might actually have fewer people getting all the way through successfully, but I think that's okay because a lot of those people were probably not the right people for your product, which means they wouldn't have been engaged customers, they probably would have churned.
text_ko: 사실 제가 생각하기에, 제대로 하고 있다면 가끔 전환율이 조금 떨어지는 게 맞는 것 같아요. 그래서 성공적으로 끝까지 가는 사람이 줄어들 수도 있는데, 그게 괜찮다고 생각해요. 왜냐하면 그런 사람들 중 많은 이들이 아마도 당신의 제품에 적합하지 않은 사람들이었을 테니까요. 그러면 그들은 고객으로서도 잘 참여하지 않았을 거고, 아마 이탈(churn)했을 가능성이 높아요.
text_zh: 我认为如果你做得对，有时候转化率（conversion）实际上应该稍微下降。这可能意味着成功完成购买的人数会减少，但我认为这没关系，因为很多人可能并不适合你的产品，这意味着他们不会成为活跃客户，最终可能会流失（churn）。
text_es: En realidad, creo que si lo estás haciendo bien, a veces la tasa de conversión (conversion rate) debería disminuir un poco. Puede que tengas menos personas que lleguen hasta el final con éxito, pero creo que eso está bien, porque muchas de esas personas probablemente no eran las adecuadas para tu producto, lo que significa que no habrían sido clientes comprometidos (engaged customers) y probablemente habrían abandonado (churned).
context: Lenny asks Adam how to think about onboarding as a conversion opportunity versus retention opportunity. Adam explains a counterintuitive principle: good onboarding optimization might actually reduce conversion rates slightly. He argues this is beneficial because it filters out unqualified users who would likely churn anyway, resulting in higher quality users who are more likely to retain and succeed with the product.
vocabulary_highlights: getting all the way through, engaged customers, probably would have churned

speaker: Adam Fishman
speaker_expertise: Product Management, B2B SaaS, Product Strategy
text: When you're interviewing at a company, you are actually investing an even more scarce resource. You're investing your time. There is no way to get more time. We're all on a finite clock. You can always get more money. If you make a bad investment decision, 'Okay, we lost there.' Provided you didn't bankrupt yourself. Even if you did, you can climb out of bankruptcy. There are things that you can do, but time is fleeting.
text_ko: 회사를 인터뷰할 때, 사실 더 귀한 자원에 투자하고 있는 거예요. 바로 시간이에요. 시간은 절대 늘릴 수 없잖아요. 우리 모두 한정된 시간 안에 살고 있어요. 돈은 언제든지 더 벌 수 있지만, 잘못된 투자 결정을 내리면 '아, 여기서 손해봤네.' 하고 넘어갈 수 있어요. 파산하지 않는 한, 파산해도 다시 일어설 수 있는 방법이 있죠. 하지만 시간은 정말 빠르게 지나가요.
text_zh: 在面试公司时，实际上你是在投资一种更加稀缺的资源，那就是时间。时间是无法再生的，我们每个人的时间都是有限的。你可以随时赚到更多的钱。如果做出了错误的投资决策，没关系，“我们在这里亏了。”只要你没有破产。即使破产了，你也可以东山再起。但时间是转瞬即逝的。
text_es: Cuando estás en una entrevista en una empresa, en realidad estás invirtiendo un recurso aún más escaso. Estás invirtiendo tu tiempo. No hay forma de recuperar el tiempo. Todos estamos en un reloj finito. Siempre puedes conseguir más dinero. Si tomas una mala decisión de inversión, 'Está bien, perdimos ahí.' Siempre y cuando no te hayas arruinado. Incluso si lo hiciste, puedes salir de la bancarrota. Hay cosas que puedes hacer, pero el tiempo es efímero.
context: Lenny asks for tips on evaluating whether people at a company are a good fit before joining. Adam draws an analogy between job hunting and investing, explaining that candidates should do as much diligence as investors do when evaluating companies. He emphasizes that when you join a company, you're investing your most precious resource - time - which unlike money, can never be recovered once lost.
vocabulary_highlights: even more scarce resource, finite clock, climb out of bankruptcy, time is fleeting

speaker: Adam Grenier
text: One of the biggest pieces of advice I'm giving to people that are like, "How should we adjust our marketing with the economic changes and things like that?" I was like, "Start by assuming you no longer have product market fit, because you had product market fit in a different market." It's a different market now, so you have to start over. And hopefully you do, or it's pretty close to it and you just have to adjust a couple things, and you could be right back on track.
text_ko: 경제 변화에 맞춰 마케팅을 어떻게 조정해야 할지 고민하는 분들에게 제가 주는 가장 큰 조언 중 하나는, "이제는 제품 시장 적합성(product market fit)이 없다고 가정해 보세요. 왜냐하면 예전 시장에서는 있었지만, 지금은 다른 시장이니까요."라고 말하는 거예요. 지금은 다른 시장이니까 다시 시작해야 해요. 다행히도 다시 시작할 필요가 없거나 거의 비슷한 상태라면 몇 가지만 조정하면 다시 제 궤도로 돌아갈 수 있을 거예요.
text_zh: 我给那些问“我们应该如何根据经济变化调整市场营销？”的人最大的建议之一是：“首先假设你们不再拥有产品市场契合度（product market fit），因为你们在不同的市场中曾经有过产品市场契合度。”现在市场不同了，所以你们必须重新开始。希望你们确实能做到，或者情况接近，只需调整几个方面，就能重新回到正轨。
text_es: Uno de los consejos más importantes que doy a las personas que preguntan: "¿Cómo deberíamos ajustar nuestro marketing con los cambios económicos y cosas así?" es: "Empiecen por asumir que ya no tienen un ajuste producto-mercado (product market fit), porque lo tenían en un mercado diferente." Ahora es un mercado distinto, así que deben empezar de nuevo. Y ojalá lo hagan, o que esté bastante cerca y solo necesiten ajustar un par de cosas para volver a estar en el camino correcto.
context: Lenny is discussing how companies need to adapt when their initial customer base changes or when market conditions shift. Adam explains his advice for companies dealing with economic changes and market shifts. He argues that companies often mistakenly think they just need to find new marketing channels when the real issue is that their entire customer base and market context has fundamentally changed, requiring them to reassess their product-market fit from scratch.
vocabulary_highlights: adjust a couple things, right back on track

speaker: Adam Grenier
text: So, I think generally the whole suite of skills that you develop in improv are pretty applicable, right? Because you are getting comfortable on your feet with change, with teamwork, building off of each other, experimenting, trying new things, a little bit of everything. I think a couple of the key rules or themes of improv that I really try to hammer home with people are obviously the "Yes, and..." side of improv, which everyone's probably heard, which is in a scene the worst thing you could do is deny somebody, because you're actually just stopping progress and you're not building off of anything.
text_ko: 그래서 제가 생각하기에 즉흥 연극(improv)에서 배우는 다양한 기술들이 정말 유용하다고 봐요. 변화에 적응하고, 팀워크를 이루고, 서로의 아이디어를 발전시키고, 실험하고, 새로운 것들을 시도하는 데 익숙해지니까요. 제가 사람들에게 강조하는 즉흥 연극의 몇 가지 핵심 규칙이나 주제 중 하나는 바로 "Yes, and..."라는 거예요. 아마 다들 들어봤을 텐데, 장면에서 누군가를 부정하는 게 가장 안 좋은 행동이라는 거죠. 그건 사실 진행을 멈추는 거고, 아무것도 발전시키지 못하는 거니까요.
text_zh: 我认为即兴表演所培养的技能整体上都是非常适用的，对吧？因为你在变化中变得更加灵活，学会团队合作，互相支持，进行实验，尝试新事物，涵盖了方方面面。我认为即兴表演中几个关键的规则或主题是我特别想强调的，显然，“是的，而且……”（Yes, and...）是其中之一，大家可能都听说过。在一个场景中，最糟糕的事情就是否定别人，因为这实际上是在阻碍进展，而不是在建立任何东西。
text_es: Creo que, en general, todo el conjunto de habilidades que desarrollas en la improvisación es bastante aplicable, ¿verdad? Porque te vuelves más ágil ante el cambio, trabajas en equipo, construyes sobre las ideas de los demás, experimentas, pruebas cosas nuevas, un poco de todo. Creo que un par de las reglas o temas clave de la improvisación que realmente trato de enfatizar con las personas son, por supuesto, el concepto de "Sí, y..." que probablemente todos han escuchado. En una escena, lo peor que puedes hacer es negar a alguien, porque en realidad estás deteniendo el progreso y no estás construyendo sobre nada.
context: Lenny asks Adam what he's taken away from improv that has helped him become better at work. Adam explains how improv skills translate directly to business environments. He describes the fundamental improv principle of "Yes, and..." - the idea that instead of rejecting or denying someone's ideas in a scene, you should accept them and build upon them. Adam argues this creates better collaboration and progress in business settings compared to simply shutting down ideas.
vocabulary_highlights: on your feet, hammer home, building off of

speaker: Adam Grenier
text: I hear it every now and then. I don't usually literally say it. I think one of the areas that I've found it to be valuable is when you've got cross-functional work. So, obviously at Uber we dealt with city teams a lot, and so a lot of the times the way that the central team would scope a problem versus a local team would scope a problem, would almost feel at odds with each other.
text_ko: 가끔씩 듣는 말이에요. 제가 보통은 그렇게 직접적으로 말하진 않지만, 제가 가치 있다고 느끼는 부분 중 하나는 크로스 펑셔널(cross-functional) 작업을 할 때예요. 예를 들어, 우버에서는 도시 팀들과 많이 협업했는데, 중앙 팀이 문제를 정의하는 방식과 지역 팀이 문제를 정의하는 방식이 서로 상충하는 느낌이 들 때가 많았어요.
text_zh: 我时不时会听到这个观点。我通常不会字面上表达出来。我认为它在跨职能工作中非常有价值。显然，在优步（Uber），我们与城市团队的合作非常频繁，因此中央团队与地方团队在界定问题时，往往会感到彼此之间存在矛盾。
text_es: Lo escucho de vez en cuando. No suelo decirlo de manera literal. Creo que una de las áreas donde he encontrado valor es en el trabajo interfuncional (cross-functional work). En Uber, por ejemplo, trabajamos mucho con los equipos de las ciudades, y muchas veces la forma en que el equipo central definía un problema y la forma en que un equipo local lo hacía parecían estar en desacuerdo.
context: Lenny asks Adam for specific examples of how he uses the "Yes, and..." principle from improv in actual business meetings and collaboration. Adam explains how this approach is particularly valuable in cross-functional work, using his experience at Uber as an example. He describes how central teams and local city teams often had conflicting perspectives on problems, and how the "Yes, and..." mindset helped bridge these differences rather than creating adversarial relationships.
vocabulary_highlights: cross-functional, scope a problem, at odds with each other

speaker: Adam Grenier
text: That's one. I would say that I'll say that all the time to people, "Do some improv classes." And I get a lot of people like, "No, I'm not funny," or, "I don't want to do improv." And I think it's still a really great class to take, even if you have zero interest in doing improv, or public speaking, or any of that kind of stuff. Because, again, improv 101 is taught everywhere. Every city has it somewhere, and it's rarely ever people that are trying to do improv professionally.
text_ko: 그거 하나 말씀드릴게요. 저는 항상 사람들에게 "즉흥 연극 수업을 들어보세요"라고 얘기해요. 그런데 많은 사람들이 "아니, 나는 웃기지 않아" 혹은 "즉흥 연극 하고 싶지 않아"라고 반응하더라고요. 하지만 즉흥 연극 수업은 정말 좋은 수업이에요. 즉흥 연극이나 발표에 전혀 관심이 없더라도 말이죠. 왜냐하면 즉흥 연극 101은 어디서나 배울 수 있고, 대부분의 수업은 전문적으로 즉흥 연극을 하려는 사람들이 아닌 경우가 많거든요.
text_zh: 这是一个建议。我经常对人们说：“去上些即兴表演（improv）课程。”但很多人会说：“不，我不好笑”或者“我不想做即兴表演。”我认为即使你对即兴表演、公众演讲或类似的事情没有任何兴趣，这门课仍然是非常值得上的。因为，即兴表演101在各地都有开设，每个城市都有这样的课程，而参加的人很少是想要专业从事即兴表演的。
text_es: Eso es uno. Yo diría que siempre les digo a las personas: "Tomen clases de improvisación." Y recibo muchas respuestas como: "No, no soy gracioso," o "No quiero hacer improvisación." Pero creo que es una clase realmente valiosa, incluso si no tienes ningún interés en hacer improvisación, hablar en público, o ese tipo de cosas. Porque, nuevamente, la improvisación 101 se enseña en todas partes. Cada ciudad tiene algún lugar donde se ofrece, y rara vez son personas que intentan hacer improvisación de manera profesional.
context: Lenny asks Adam what advice he has for people who want to develop better collaboration skills like the "Yes, and..." approach from improv. Adam strongly recommends taking improv classes, even for people who have no interest in comedy or performing. He explains that improv classes are widely available and mostly filled with regular people, not aspiring comedians, making them accessible for business professionals who want to improve their collaborative and communication skills.
vocabulary_highlights: zero interest, rarely ever

speaker: Adam Grenier
text: So, the exploring emerging channels framework that I'll take, either my teams or companies that I'm advising through, has three core ingredients that I like to spend time with. So, the first is really understanding if there is an overlap between what the customers need is, what your company's goals are, and what the channel actually does really well.
text_ko: 제가 다룰 신흥 채널 탐색 프레임워크는 제가 조언하는 팀이나 회사와 함께 시간을 보내는 세 가지 핵심 요소가 있어요. 첫 번째는 고객의 필요, 회사의 목표, 그리고 그 채널이 잘하는 것 사이에 겹치는 부분이 있는지를 정말로 이해하는 거예요.
text_zh: 我将要带领我的团队或我所顾问的公司探索新兴渠道的框架有三个核心要素，我希望花时间去深入理解。首先，真正理解客户需求、公司目标与渠道优势之间是否存在重叠。
text_es: El marco de exploración de canales emergentes que utilizaré, ya sea con mis equipos o con las empresas a las que asesoro, tiene tres ingredientes clave en los que me gusta profundizar. El primero es entender si hay una coincidencia entre las necesidades de los clientes, los objetivos de la empresa y lo que el canal realmente hace bien.
context: Lenny asks Adam about his framework for deciding when to invest in emerging acquisition channels like TikTok, Clubhouse, or VR. Adam introduces his systematic approach for evaluating new marketing channels, which he uses when advising companies. His framework focuses on finding the intersection of three key factors: customer needs, company goals, and the channel's unique strengths. This helps companies avoid the common mistake of chasing every new hot platform without strategic consideration.
vocabulary_highlights: core ingredients, does really well

speaker: Adam Grenier
text: The second is the channel DNA. And so this is looking at things like where are they in their trajectory? So, Clubhouse is actually a perfect example, because in a weird way, so Clubhouse got hot before Facebook got cold. And I was pretty amazed how many more people were trying to crack Clubhouse than TikTok, because TikTok hadn't really released their ads solution yet, but neither had Clubhouse.
text_ko: 두 번째는 채널 DNA예요. 그래서 이건 그들이 지금 어떤 경로에 있는지를 보는 거죠. 클럽하우스(Clubhouse)가 딱 좋은 예인데, 이상하게도 클럽하우스가 뜨기 전에 페이스북이 식었어요. 클럽하우스를 해보려는 사람들이 틱톡(TikTok)보다 훨씬 많다는 게 정말 놀라웠어요. 왜냐하면 틱톡은 광고 솔루션을 아직 출시하지 않았고, 클럽하우스도 마찬가지였거든요.
text_zh: 第二个是渠道DNA。这是关注他们在发展轨迹中的位置。例如，Clubhouse就是一个完美的例子，因为在某种奇怪的情况下，Clubhouse在Facebook变冷之前就已经火了。我很惊讶有这么多人试图攻克Clubhouse，而不是TikTok，因为TikTok当时还没有推出广告解决方案，Clubhouse也是如此。
text_es: El segundo aspecto es el ADN del canal. Esto implica analizar aspectos como en qué etapa se encuentran en su trayectoria. Clubhouse es un ejemplo perfecto, porque de una manera curiosa, Clubhouse se volvió popular antes de que Facebook comenzara a perder interés. Me sorprendió la cantidad de personas que intentaban descifrar Clubhouse en comparación con TikTok, ya que TikTok aún no había lanzado su solución publicitaria, pero Clubhouse tampoco lo había hecho.
context: Adam continues explaining his framework for evaluating emerging marketing channels. After discussing the first factor (alignment between customer needs, company goals, and channel strengths), he moves to the second factor: "channel DNA." This involves analyzing where the platform is in its growth trajectory and development stage. He uses Clubhouse as an example, noting how many companies rushed to experiment with Clubhouse despite it being very early-stage, while overlooking more mature platforms like TikTok that might offer better opportunities.
vocabulary_highlights: channel DNA, in their trajectory, trying to crack

speaker: Adam Grenier
text: Generally I wouldn't let anything bleed past a quarter. You can probably get some good signal in a month or less, what I would call fishing. It wouldn't be like you're just putting bait in the water to figure out where the fish are, not necessarily getting statistically significant repeatable solutions.
text_ko: 보통은 3개월 이상 끌지 않아요. 한 달 이내에 좋은 신호를 얻을 수 있을 거예요. 이걸 저는 '낚시(fishing)'라고 부르는데, 물에 미끼를 던져서 물고기가 어디 있는지 알아보는 것과 같아요. 통계적으로 의미 있는 반복 가능한 결과를 얻는 건 아니죠.
text_zh: 一般来说，我不会让任何事情拖延超过一个季度。你可能在一个月或更短的时间内就能获得一些有效的信息，这我称之为“试探”。这并不是说你只是把饵放进水里去找鱼，而是并不一定能得到具有统计显著性和可重复性的解决方案。
text_es: En general, no permitiría que nada se extienda más allá de un trimestre. Probablemente puedas obtener algunas señales útiles en un mes o menos, lo que yo llamaría "pesca". No sería como simplemente lanzar un cebo al agua para averiguar dónde están los peces, sin necesariamente obtener soluciones repetibles y estadísticamente significativas.
context: Lenny asks Adam for practical advice on how long companies should spend testing new marketing channels before deciding whether to continue or abandon them. Adam provides specific timeframes, suggesting that most experiments shouldn't extend beyond a quarter (three months). He uses a fishing metaphor to describe the initial testing phase - you're trying to get early signals and understand the potential rather than expecting immediate, statistically significant results from these emerging channels.
vocabulary_highlights: bleed past, putting bait in the water, statistically significant

speaker: Adriel Frederick
text: There are probably, I call them techno utopians who would say, feed all data to the algorithm, give it an objective, and it will do the right thing. And I was like yeah, the reason that falls down is the algorithms don't understand long term effects often, nor do they understand how people might respond to it, nor do they understand your intent for the product, and I think it's really important for product managers to play that role.
text_ko: 아마도 저는 그런 사람들을 테크노 유토피아인이라고 부르는데, 데이터는 다 알고리즘에 주고 목표만 주면 잘 할 거라고 생각해요. 그런데 그게 잘 안 되는 이유는 알고리즘이 장기적인 효과를 잘 이해하지 못하고, 사람들이 어떻게 반응할지도 모르고, 제품에 대한 당신의 의도도 이해하지 못하기 때문이에요. 그래서 제품 매니저가 그런 역할을 하는 게 정말 중요하다고 생각해요.
text_zh: 我称他们为技术乌托邦主义者，他们可能会说，把所有数据输入算法，设定一个目标，它就会做出正确的决策。但我认为，这种想法的缺陷在于，算法往往无法理解长期影响，也无法理解人们可能的反应，更无法理解你对产品的意图。因此，产品经理在这个过程中扮演着非常重要的角色。
text_es: Probablemente hay quienes yo llamo utopistas tecnológicos que dirían que hay que alimentar todos los datos al algoritmo, darle un objetivo y este hará lo correcto. Y yo pienso que el problema con eso es que los algoritmos a menudo no comprenden los efectos a largo plazo, ni cómo las personas podrían responder a ellos, ni entienden tu intención con el producto. Creo que es realmente importante que los gerentes de producto (product managers) asuman ese rol.
context: Lenny and Adriel are discussing the role of algorithms in product development and the balance between automated decision-making and human oversight. Adriel is explaining why he believes purely algorithmic approaches to product development are insufficient. He argues that while some people advocate for letting algorithms handle all decisions based on data and objectives, this approach has fundamental limitations that require human product managers to intervene and guide the process.
vocabulary_highlights: techno utopians, falls down, intent for the product
topics: Product Management, Strategy & Planning, Decision Making

speaker: Adriel Frederick
text: When you recognize that you get business value from it, then it all of a sudden becomes something that you look out for and you take care of. That's it. And there's definitely a lot more to it, but I think when it goes from frankly something people feel they need to do to be PC or for cultural reasons or because they're getting social pressure to do it to something that you really recognize concretely, no, I get value from this and you are willing to take the other steps to have a culture at your company that utilizes it, then it becomes easy because when you bring folks in from diverse backgrounds, they retain and that's always the number one step to growth as you will know.
text_ko: 비즈니스에서 가치를 느끼게 되면, 갑자기 그걸 챙기고 신경 쓰게 돼요. 그게 전부예요. 물론 그 뒤에는 더 많은 것들이 있지만, 사람들이 단순히 정치적 올바름(PC)이나 문화적 이유, 아니면 사회적 압박 때문에 해야 한다고 느끼는 것에서, '아, 이건 정말 나에게 가치를 주는구나'라고 인식하게 되면, 그때부터는 회사에서 이를 활용할 수 있는 문화를 만들기 위해 다른 조치를 취할 의지가 생겨요. 그러면 쉽게 되죠. 다양한 배경을 가진 사람들을 영입하면 그들이 잘 정착하고, 그게 항상 성장의 첫걸음이니까요.
text_zh: 当你意识到从中获得商业价值时，它突然间就变成了你关注和维护的对象。这就是关键。虽然其中还有很多内容，但我认为，当某件事情从人们出于政治正确（PC）或文化原因，或者因为社会压力而不得不做的事情，转变为你真正意识到从中获得了具体的价值，并愿意采取其他措施在公司内建立一种利用它的文化时，这一切就变得简单了。因为当你引入来自不同背景的人时，他们会留任，而这始终是你所知道的增长的第一步。
text_es: Cuando reconoces que obtienes valor comercial de ello, de repente se convierte en algo que buscas y cuidas. Eso es todo. Y definitivamente hay mucho más, pero creo que cuando pasa de ser algo que la gente siente que necesita hacer por razones de corrección política (PC) o culturales, o por presión social, a algo que realmente reconoces de manera concreta, es decir, que obtienes valor de esto y estás dispuesto a tomar los otros pasos para tener una cultura en tu empresa que lo utilice, entonces se vuelve fácil, porque cuando incorporas personas de diversos orígenes, se quedan, y eso siempre es el primer paso hacia el crecimiento, como bien sabes.
context: Lenny asks Adriel about what he's learned regarding how to foster diversity at companies, given that Adriel was the first Black product manager at Facebook. Adriel is explaining his key insight about what makes diversity initiatives successful at companies. He argues that diversity efforts work best when companies recognize the concrete business value rather than pursuing diversity for social or political correctness reasons, and emphasizes that retention is crucial for any diversity program to succeed.
vocabulary_highlights: all of a sudden, to be PC, look out for, take the other steps

speaker: Adriel Frederick
text: I think some controversy is necessary and so I may be at a different point on that one. I don't think you're going to have any meaningful influence on the world without changing some pattern of behavior. And if you're changing a pattern of behavior, there's somebody who's invested in that pattern of behavior and that's going to create some conflict.
text_ko: 저는 어느 정도 논란이 필요하다고 생각해요. 그래서 그 부분에 대해서는 좀 다른 의견일 수도 있어요. 세상에 의미 있는 영향을 미치려면 행동 패턴을 바꿔야 한다고 생각해요. 행동 패턴을 바꾸면 그 패턴에 투자한 사람들이 있기 때문에 갈등이 생길 수밖에 없죠.
text_zh: 我认为适度的争议是必要的，因此我可能在这一点上与您有所不同。我认为，如果不改变某些行为模式，您将无法对世界产生任何有意义的影响。而如果您在改变某种行为模式，就会有一些人对此模式有所依赖，这必然会引发冲突。
text_es: Creo que cierta controversia es necesaria, por lo que puedo tener una opinión diferente al respecto. No creo que puedas tener una influencia significativa en el mundo sin cambiar algún patrón de comportamiento. Y si estás cambiando un patrón de comportamiento, hay alguien que está invertido en ese patrón y eso va a generar algún conflicto.
context: Lenny observes that Adriel has worked at several controversial companies like Facebook, Lyft, and Reddit, and asks what he's learned about operating as a product leader at companies that face frequent criticism and bad PR. Adriel is explaining his philosophy that controversy is often inevitable when building meaningful products. He argues that creating real impact requires changing existing behaviors, which naturally creates conflict with those who benefit from the status quo.
vocabulary_highlights: at a different point, meaningful influence, invested in that pattern, create some conflict

speaker: Adriel Frederick
text: I think growth hacking as traditionally assigned, finding those small changes you can make to a product to give you outsized impact, that is absolutely valuable. Where I've seen people get lost is they assume that if you do that alone, it will work. You can grow your way into something successful if you just find those few hacks and patch them together. And there's something about that that I find disrespectful to the people using the product.
text_ko: 저는 전통적으로 성장 해킹(growth hacking)이라고 하는, 제품에 작은 변화를 주어서 큰 영향을 주는 방법이 정말 가치 있다고 생각해요. 그런데 사람들이 자주 헷갈리는 점은, 그걸 혼자서만 하면 성공할 거라고 생각하는 거예요. 몇 가지 해킹(hacks)을 찾아서 조합하면 성공할 수 있다고 믿는 거죠. 그런데 그렇게 생각하는 건 제품을 사용하는 사람들에 대한 예의가 아닌 것 같아요.
text_zh: 我认为传统意义上的增长黑客（growth hacking），即寻找那些可以对产品产生巨大影响的小改动，确实是非常有价值的。然而，我看到很多人误以为仅仅依靠这些小改动就能成功。他们认为只要找到几个黑客（hacks）并将其拼凑在一起，就能实现增长。我觉得这种想法对使用产品的人是不尊重的。
text_es: Creo que el "growth hacking" (crecimiento acelerado), tal como se ha definido tradicionalmente, es valioso al encontrar esos pequeños cambios que puedes hacer en un producto para lograr un impacto desproporcionado. Donde he visto que las personas se pierden es al asumir que si lo hacen por su cuenta, funcionará. Puedes crecer hacia algo exitoso si solo encuentras esos pocos "hacks" y los unes. Y hay algo en eso que considero irrespetuoso hacia las personas que utilizan el producto.
context: Lenny asks Adriel about his learnings on growth and growth hacking from his time at Facebook's growth team and other companies. Adriel is explaining his nuanced view on growth hacking - while he sees value in tactical optimizations that can create outsized impact, he warns against relying solely on these tactics. He argues that depending only on growth hacks without providing real fundamental value is ultimately disrespectful to users and unsustainable.
vocabulary_highlights: traditionally assigned, outsized impact, get lost, patch them together, disrespectful

speaker: Adriel Frederick
text: For me, it's a person who is just on the cusp of taking the action you want to take. I'll give you the concrete example. When working on registration, I would try to find a country where we had a lot of growth, but for some reason our conversion rates were terrible. So we had a lot of traffic, but conversion rates were terrible. And I was like, okay, that's the marginal user.
text_ko: 저한테는 원하는 행동을 막 하려는 사람을 의미해요. 구체적인 예를 들어볼게요. 등록 작업을 할 때, 성장률이 높은 나라를 찾으려고 했는데, 이상하게도 전환율이 정말 낮았어요. 그래서 방문자는 많았는데 전환율은 형편없었죠. 그래서 저는 그걸 한계 사용자(marginal user)라고 생각했어요.
text_zh: 对我来说，这个人正好处于采取你想要的行动的边缘。我给你一个具体的例子。在进行注册工作时，我会尝试找一个我们增长很快的国家，但出于某种原因，我们的转化率却很糟糕。所以我们有很多流量，但转化率却很低。我想，这就是边际用户。
text_es: Para mí, es una persona que está a punto de tomar la acción que deseas que tome. Te daré un ejemplo concreto. Al trabajar en el registro, intentaba encontrar un país donde tuviéramos un gran crecimiento, pero por alguna razón nuestras tasas de conversión eran terribles. Teníamos mucho tráfico, pero las tasas de conversión eran muy bajas. Y pensé, está bien, ese es el usuario marginal.
context: Lenny asks Adriel to unpack what he means by the term 'marginal user,' which Adriel had mentioned earlier as a key focus for growth optimization. Adriel is defining this concept by explaining that marginal users are people who are almost ready to take a desired action but haven't quite gotten there yet. He provides a concrete example from his Facebook experience of identifying marginal users by looking for markets with high traffic but low conversion rates.
vocabulary_highlights: on the cusp, concrete example, marginal user

speaker: Adriel Frederick
text: Organization design and empathy. Oh dude, for a long time, and I think this is, I and many others had this idea that the people who are the smartest are the ones who rise. The people who are the most technically competent are the ones who rise. People who are the best individual contributors are the ones who rise. And somewhere along the way I had that idea disabused of me and I recognize the job's different.
text_ko: 조직 설계와 공감에 대해 이야기해볼게요. 한동안 저도 그렇고 많은 사람들이 가장 똑똑한 사람들이 성공한다고 생각했어요. 기술적으로 가장 능숙한 사람들이 올라간다고 믿었고, 개인적으로 가장 잘하는 사람들이 성공한다고 생각했죠. 그런데 어느 순간 그 생각이 바뀌었고, 일이 다르다는 걸 깨달았어요.
text_zh: 组织设计与同理心。很长一段时间以来，我和许多人都有这样的想法：最聪明的人是那些能够晋升的人；技术能力最强的人是那些能够晋升的人；表现最出色的个人贡献者是那些能够晋升的人。然而，在某个时刻，我意识到这个想法是错误的，我认识到工作的本质是不同的。
text_es: Diseño organizacional y empatía. Durante mucho tiempo, yo y muchos otros pensamos que las personas más inteligentes son las que ascienden. Que los que tienen mayor competencia técnica son los que avanzan. Que los mejores colaboradores individuales son los que logran el éxito. Sin embargo, en algún momento me di cuenta de que el trabajo es diferente.
context: Lenny asks Adriel what skills he's had to grow most as he's advanced from individual contributor to VP of Product at Reddit. Adriel identifies organization design and empathy as the two most critical skills he's developed. He explains that early in his career, like many others, he believed that being the smartest or most technically competent person would lead to advancement, but he learned that leadership roles require fundamentally different skills focused on building and managing teams effectively.
vocabulary_highlights: had that idea disabused of me, the ones who rise, individual contributors

speaker: Aishwarya Naresh Reganti
speaker_expertise: AI/ML Products, Product Strategy, Product Management
text: Most people tend to ignore the non-determinism. You don't know how the user might behave with your product, and you also don't know how the LLM might respond to that. The second difference is the agency control trade-off. Every time you hand over decision-making capabilities to agentic systems, you're kind of relinquishing some amount of control on your end.
text_ko: 대부분의 사람들은 비결정론(non-determinism)을 간과하는 경향이 있어요. 사용자가 제품을 가지고 어떻게 행동할지, 그리고 LLM이 그에 대해 어떻게 반응할지 알 수 없거든요. 두 번째 차이점은 에이전시 제어의 트레이드오프(agency control trade-off)예요. 에이전틱 시스템에 의사결정 능력을 넘길 때마다, 어느 정도의 통제를 포기하는 거라고 할 수 있어요.
text_zh: 大多数人往往忽视非确定性（non-determinism）。你无法预测用户如何使用你的产品，也无法预知大型语言模型（LLM）会如何回应。第二个区别是代理控制的权衡（agency control trade-off）。每次将决策能力交给代理系统时，你实际上是在放弃一定程度的控制权。
text_es: La mayoría de las personas tienden a ignorar el no determinismo. No sabes cómo se comportará el usuario con tu producto, y tampoco sabes cómo responderá el LLM (modelo de lenguaje grande) a eso. La segunda diferencia es el equilibrio entre el control y la agencia. Cada vez que delegas capacidades de toma de decisiones a sistemas agentivos, estás cediendo un cierto grado de control de tu parte.
context: Lenny asks Aishwarya to explain the key insight from their guest post about how building AI products is fundamentally different from building traditional software products. Aishwarya identifies two critical differences that most product builders overlook. The first is non-determinism - unlike traditional software where user interactions and outputs are predictable, AI products involve unpredictable user inputs through natural language and unpredictable AI responses. The second is the agency control trade-off - as you give AI systems more autonomy to make decisions, you lose control over outcomes.
vocabulary_highlights: hand over decision-making capabilities, agentic systems, relinquishing some amount of control
topics: Product Management, Strategy & Planning, Decision Making

speaker: Kiriti Badam
text: When you start small, it forces you to think about what is the problem that I'm going to solve. In all this advancements of the AI, one easy, slippery slope is to keep thinking about complexities of the solution and forget the problem that you're trying to solve.
text_ko: 작게 시작하면 해결해야 할 문제가 뭐인지 고민하게 돼요. AI가 발전하면서, 복잡한 해결책에만 집중하다가 진짜 해결해야 할 문제를 잊어버리기 쉬운 함정이 있어요.
text_zh: 当你从小规模开始时，这迫使你思考自己要解决的问题。在人工智能（AI）不断发展的过程中，一个容易陷入的误区就是不断关注解决方案的复杂性，而忽视了你真正要解决的问题。
text_es: Cuando comienzas pequeño, te obliga a reflexionar sobre cuál es el problema que vas a resolver. En medio de todos estos avances de la IA (AI), una trampa fácil y resbaladiza es seguir pensando en las complejidades de la solución y olvidar el problema que estás tratando de resolver.
context: Lenny asks for examples of how to start with low agency and high control when building AI products. Kiriti explains their core recommendation to start small rather than jumping immediately to fully autonomous AI agents. He emphasizes that starting small forces you to focus on the actual problem you're solving rather than getting overwhelmed by AI capabilities. This prevents the common mistake of being solution-first rather than problem-first when building AI products.
vocabulary_highlights: slippery slope, complexities of the solution
topics: Product Management, Strategy & Planning, Starting a Company

speaker: Aishwarya Naresh Reganti
speaker_expertise: AI/ML Products, Product Strategy, Product Management
text: It's not about being the first company to have an agent among your competitors. It's about have you built the right flywheels in place so that you can improve over time.
text_ko: 경쟁사 중에서 가장 먼저 에이전트를 도입하는 게 중요한 게 아니에요. 중요한 건 시간이 지나면서 개선할 수 있도록 올바른 플라이휠(flywheel)을 만들어 놓았느냐는 거예요.
text_zh: 这并不是关于在竞争对手中率先拥有代理（agent）的问题，而是你是否建立了正确的飞轮（flywheel），以便能够随着时间的推移不断改进。
text_es: No se trata de ser la primera empresa en tener un agente entre tus competidores. Se trata de si has construido los engranajes adecuados (flywheels) para poder mejorar con el tiempo.
context: Aishwarya is explaining successful patterns she sees in companies that build AI products well. She's emphasizing that success in AI products isn't about racing to deploy autonomous agents first, but rather about building systems that can continuously learn and improve. A flywheel in this context refers to a self-reinforcing cycle where user interactions generate data that helps improve the AI system, which leads to better user experiences and more interactions.
vocabulary_highlights: built the right flywheels in place
topics: Product Management, Strategy & Planning, Growth & Marketing

speaker: Aishwarya Naresh Reganti
speaker_expertise: AI/ML Products, Product Strategy, Product Management
text: Leaders have to get back to being hands-on. You must be comfortable with the fact that your intuitions might not be right. And you probably are the dumbest person in the room and you want to learn from everyone.
text_ko: 리더는 다시 직접 나서야 해요. 자신의 직감이 항상 맞지 않을 수도 있다는 걸 받아들여야 하고요. 그리고 아마도 방에서 가장 멍청한 사람일 수도 있으니, 모든 사람에게서 배우고 싶어야 해요.
text_zh: 领导者需要重新回到实地操作的状态。你必须接受你的直觉可能并不总是正确的。而且，你可能是房间里最愚蠢的人，应该向每个人学习。
text_es: Los líderes deben volver a involucrarse de manera activa. Deben estar dispuestos a aceptar que sus intuiciones pueden no ser correctas. Y probablemente sean la persona menos sabia en la sala y deseen aprender de todos.
context: Lenny asks about ways of working that successful AI companies demonstrate. Aishwarya explains that one key pattern is leaders needing to rebuild their intuitions about technology. She gives an example of a CEO who blocked time every morning from 4-6 AM to catch up on AI developments. The key insight is that experienced leaders must be humble and willing to learn from everyone because their traditional business intuitions may not apply to AI products.
vocabulary_highlights: get back to being hands-on, dumbest person in the room

speaker: Kiriti Badam
text: Persistence is extremely valuable. Successful companies right now building in any new area, they are going through the pain of learning this, implementing this and understanding what works and what doesn't work. Pain is the new moat.
text_ko: 지속성이 정말 중요해요. 지금 새로운 분야에서 성공적인 회사들은 이 과정을 겪으면서 배우고, 실행하고, 어떤 게 효과가 있고 어떤 게 효과가 없는지 이해하고 있어요. 이 고통이 새로운 방어선이 되고 있죠.
text_zh: 坚持是极其重要的。目前，成功的公司在任何新领域的发展中，都在经历学习、实施以及理解什么有效、什么无效的痛苦。痛苦就是新的护城河。
text_es: La persistencia es extremadamente valiosa. Las empresas exitosas que actualmente están incursionando en nuevas áreas están atravesando el proceso doloroso de aprender, implementar y entender lo que funciona y lo que no. El dolor se ha convertido en la nueva ventaja competitiva.
context: Lenny asks what Kiriti thinks the next year of AI will look like. Kiriti introduces his concept that "pain is the new moat" - meaning that the competitive advantage for companies comes from going through the difficult process of learning how to build AI products effectively. Unlike traditional moats like network effects or economies of scale, the moat in AI comes from the hard-earned knowledge gained through trial and error in implementation.
vocabulary_highlights: pain is the new moat, going through the pain
topics: Strategy & Planning, Starting a Company, Learning & Growth

speaker: Aishwarya Naresh Reganti
speaker_expertise: AI/ML Products, Product Strategy, Product Management
text: If someone's selling you one click-agents, it's pure marketing. You don't want to buy into that. I would rather go with a company that says, 'We're going to build this pipeline for you,' and that will learn over time and build a flywheel to improve than something that's going to work out of the box.
text_ko: 누군가가 원클릭 에이전트(click-agent)를 팔고 있다면, 그건 순수한 마케팅이에요. 그런 건 사지 않는 게 좋죠. 저는 '우리가 이 파이프라인(pipeline)을 만들어 줄게요'라고 말하는 회사와 함께하고 싶어요. 시간이 지나면서 배우고, 개선할 수 있는 플라이휠(flywheel)을 만들 수 있는 그런 회사가 더 낫죠.
text_zh: 如果有人向你推销一键代理（one click-agents），那纯粹是营销手段。你不应该被这种产品所吸引。我更倾向于选择一家说“我们将为你构建这个管道（pipeline）”的公司，这家公司会随着时间的推移不断学习并建立一个自我增强的循环（flywheel），而不是选择一个开箱即用的解决方案。
text_es: Si alguien te está vendiendo agentes de un clic (click-agents), es pura mercadotecnia. No querrás caer en eso. Prefiero optar por una empresa que diga: 'Vamos a construir este pipeline para ti', y que aprenda con el tiempo y desarrolle un ciclo de retroalimentación (flywheel) para mejorar, en lugar de algo que funcione directamente desde el principio.
context: Aishwarya is explaining technical patterns that successful AI companies follow. She's warning against vendors who promise immediate, fully autonomous AI solutions. Instead, she advocates for companies that focus on building systems that improve over time through continuous learning. A flywheel refers to a self-reinforcing cycle where the AI system gets better through use and feedback, rather than being a static solution that works perfectly from day one.
vocabulary_highlights: one click-agents, pure marketing, buy into that, work out of the box

speaker: Albert Cheng
text: Growth as the job is to connect users to the value of your product. Growth sometimes gets this reputation that it's just pure metrics hacking.
text_ko: 성장은 사용자와 제품의 가치를 연결하는 일이에요. 가끔 성장이라는 개념이 단순히 수치 조작으로만 여겨지기도 해요.
text_zh: 增长的任务是将用户与产品的价值连接起来。有时，增长会被认为只是单纯的指标黑客（metrics hacking）。
text_es: El crecimiento consiste en conectar a los usuarios con el valor de tu producto. A veces, el crecimiento adquiere la reputación de ser solo un juego de métricas.
context: Lenny asks Albert about his definition of growth and how to approach growth work effectively. Albert explains his core philosophy about what growth teams should focus on, contrasting it with common misconceptions about growth being purely about manipulating metrics without regard for user value.
vocabulary_highlights: pure metrics hacking

speaker: Albert Cheng
text: User retention is gold for consumer subscription companies. If you don't retain your users, then a lot of the onus is on getting them to pay on day one.
text_ko: 사용자 유지가 소비자 구독 회사에겐 정말 중요해요. 만약 사용자를 잘 유지하지 못하면, 첫날에 결제하게 만드는 게 정말 큰 부담이 되거든요.
text_zh: 用户留存对消费订阅公司来说至关重要。如果无法留住用户，那么在第一天就让他们付费的压力就会很大。
text_es: La retención de usuarios es clave para las empresas de suscripción. Si no logras retener a tus usuarios, gran parte de la responsabilidad recae en conseguir que paguen desde el primer día.
context: Lenny asks Albert what he thinks is the biggest missing piece that people don't understand about building successful consumer subscription products. Albert emphasizes that retention is the most critical factor, explaining that without good retention, companies are forced into the much harder task of converting users immediately upon signup rather than building long-term value.
vocabulary_highlights: onus is on

speaker: Albert Cheng
text: The lived product experience for most of the free users was that Grammarly was just a product to fix your spelling and grammar because those were the free suggestions. What if we actually sampled a number of different paid suggestions and interspersed them to free users across their writing? All of a sudden, people were seeing Grammarly as a much more powerful tool than they were before.
text_ko: 대부분의 무료 사용자들은 Grammarly가 단순히 맞춤법과 문법을 고치는 도구라고 생각했어요. 무료로 제공되는 제안들이 그런 인식을 만들었거든요. 만약 우리가 여러 가지 유료 제안을 샘플링해서 무료 사용자들에게 그걸 섞어서 보여준다면 어떻게 될까요? 갑자기 사람들이 Grammarly를 훨씬 더 강력한 도구로 인식하게 될 거예요.
text_zh: 大多数免费用户的使用体验是，Grammarly 只是一个用来修正拼写和语法的工具，因为他们只能获得免费的建议。如果我们实际上向一些免费用户提供不同的付费建议，并在他们的写作中穿插这些建议，会发生什么呢？突然之间，人们开始将 Grammarly 视为一个比之前更强大的工具。
text_es: La experiencia del producto para la mayoría de los usuarios gratuitos era que Grammarly era solo una herramienta para corregir la ortografía y la gramática, ya que esas eran las sugerencias disponibles sin costo. ¿Qué pasaría si realmente ofreciéramos una muestra de diferentes sugerencias de pago y las intercaláramos para los usuarios gratuitos en sus escritos? De repente, las personas comenzarían a ver Grammarly como una herramienta mucho más poderosa de lo que pensaban antes.
context: Lenny asks Albert about his biggest monetization win at Grammarly, based on a recommendation from Noam Levinsky. Albert explains how they discovered that free users only saw basic spelling and grammar corrections, giving them a limited view of Grammarly's capabilities. By mixing in samples of premium features with the free suggestions, they completely changed how users perceived the product's value.
vocabulary_highlights: lived product experience, sampled, interspersed them

speaker: Albert Cheng
text: I saw some of the highest performers just being people that had very high agency, had that clock speed, had that energy, but they didn't necessarily need to have deep experience on that matter. Sometimes experience could be a crutch, especially in this world where the grounds are shifting so fast with AI. A lot of your learned habits actually need to be intentionally discarded.
text_ko: 제가 본 최고의 성과를 내는 사람들은 대개 높은 자율성(agency)과 빠른 판단력, 에너지를 가진 사람들이었어요. 하지만 그들이 꼭 그 분야에 대한 깊은 경험이 필요했던 건 아니에요. 때로는 경험이 오히려 방해가 될 수 있어요. 특히 AI와 같은 빠르게 변화하는 세상에서는요. 우리가 배운 습관 중 많은 것들은 의도적으로 버려야 할 필요가 있어요.
text_zh: 我看到一些表现最优秀的人，他们具备很强的主动性（agency）、快速的反应能力（clock speed）和充沛的精力，但不一定需要在某个领域有深厚的经验。在这个快速变化的人工智能（AI）时代，经验有时反而可能成为一种负担。很多你习惯的做法实际上需要有意识地抛弃。
text_es: Observé que algunos de los mejores desempeños provenían de personas con una gran capacidad de acción (agency), un ritmo ágil (clock speed) y mucha energía, pero no necesariamente tenían que contar con una experiencia profunda en el tema. A veces, la experiencia puede convertirse en una muleta, especialmente en este mundo donde los cambios ocurren tan rápidamente con la inteligencia artificial (AI). Muchos de los hábitos adquiridos realmente necesitan ser desechados de manera intencionada.
context: Lenny asks Albert about the most counterintuitive lesson he's learned about building teams. Albert shares his observation that the best team members aren't always those with the most experience in a specific domain. Instead, he's found that people with high agency, quick decision-making speed, and energy often outperform more experienced candidates, particularly in rapidly changing environments where past knowledge may become obsolete.
vocabulary_highlights: clock speed, experience could be a crutch, grounds are shifting so fast, intentionally discarded

speaker: Albert Cheng
text: When you're in exploratory mode, think of it as finding the right mountain to climb. And then when you're in exploitation mode, it's like focusing your resources on climbing that mountain effectively. And certain companies, I think the warning is to basically spend too much of your time on one end of the spectrum.
text_ko: 탐색 모드에 있을 땐, 적절한 산을 찾는 과정이라고 생각해요. 그리고 활용 모드에 들어가면, 그 산을 효과적으로 오르기 위해 자원을 집중하는 거죠. 어떤 회사들은 이 스펙트럼의 한쪽에 너무 많은 시간을 쏟는 게 경고해야 할 점인 것 같아요.
text_zh: 当你处于探索阶段时，可以把它看作是在寻找合适的山峰来攀登。而当你进入开发阶段时，就像是将资源集中在有效地攀登那座山上。我认为某些公司需要警惕，避免在这个光谱的某一端花费过多的时间。
text_es: Cuando estás en modo exploratorio, piénsalo como encontrar la montaña adecuada para escalar. Y luego, cuando estás en modo de explotación, es como concentrar tus recursos en escalar esa montaña de manera efectiva. Y ciertas empresas, creo que la advertencia es que, en esencia, dedican demasiado tiempo a un extremo del espectro.
context: Lenny asks Albert to explain his 'explore and exploit' framework for finding growth opportunities. Albert describes this as a balance between two modes: exploration (finding new opportunities and testing different approaches) and exploitation (doubling down on what works). He warns that companies often get stuck focusing too heavily on one mode, either scattering their efforts across too many experiments or getting trapped in local optimization.
vocabulary_highlights: one end of the spectrum

speaker: Albert Cheng
text: You can just plug in like an analysis that another person wrote and just have it summarized for you and give you advice on ideas to go try. And so that ideation, that research cycle was much, much faster.
text_ko: 다른 사람이 쓴 분석을 그냥 연결해서 요약해주고, 시도해볼 아이디어에 대한 조언도 받을 수 있어요. 그래서 아이디어 구상(ideation)이나 연구 사이클이 훨씬 더 빨라졌죠.
text_zh: 你可以直接输入其他人撰写的分析，然后让它为你总结并提供建议，告诉你可以尝试的想法。因此，这个创意生成（ideation）和研究周期变得快得多。
text_es: Puedes simplemente introducir un análisis que otra persona escribió y obtener un resumen, además de recibir recomendaciones sobre ideas que puedes probar. De esta manera, el proceso de ideación y la investigación se volvieron mucho más rápidos.
context: Lenny asks Albert how AI is changing the work of growth professionals. Albert explains how AI tools like ChatGPT are accelerating the experiment analysis and ideation process. Previously, teams had to manually write analysis documents and extract insights from experiment results, but now AI can quickly summarize findings and suggest new ideas to test, significantly speeding up the cycle from experiment completion to next hypothesis.
vocabulary_highlights: plug in, ideation

speaker: Albert Cheng
text: Growth sometimes gets this reputation that it's just pure metrics hacking, like we're cold people that just are trying to move a particular metric up and we're going to do whatever it can to throw walls and pay walls and add friction in all these spots.
text_ko: 성장이 가끔은 단순히 수치 조작만 하는 것처럼 보이기도 해요. 마치 우리가 차가운 사람들인 것처럼, 특정 지표를 올리기 위해서라면 어떤 방법이든 쓰고, 벽을 세우고, 유료 장벽(pay wall)을 추가하고, 모든 곳에 마찰을 주는 것처럼요.
text_zh: 增长有时会被视为单纯的指标操控，给人一种我们是冷漠的人，只是在努力提升某个指标，甚至不惜设置障碍和付费墙，增加用户的摩擦。
text_es: El crecimiento a veces se percibe como una simple manipulación de métricas, como si fuéramos personas frías que solo intentan aumentar un indicador específico y haríamos lo que fuera necesario para poner barreras y muros de pago, añadiendo fricción en todos estos puntos.
context: Lenny asks Albert to elaborate on his definition of growth as 'connecting users to the value of your product.' Albert addresses common negative perceptions of growth teams, explaining that many people view growth professionals as solely focused on manipulating metrics without caring about user experience. He contrasts this with his philosophy of thinking about users holistically and focusing on delivering genuine value.
vocabulary_highlights: pure metrics hacking, throw walls

speaker: Alex Hardiman
speaker_expertise: Product Strategy, B2B SaaS, Consumer Products
text: I think about wartime product management, right? You're coming in, and I think there was ... What I appreciated about that time inside of Facebook was that there was just this incredible humility that was needed to really understand and first diagnose what was actually happening on the platform.
text_ko: 전쟁 같은 상황에서 제품 관리를 생각해보면, 들어오는 순간부터... 제가 페이스북에서 그 시기에 정말 감사했던 점은 플랫폼에서 실제로 무슨 일이 일어나고 있는지를 이해하고 진단하기 위해 필요한 겸손함이었어요.
text_zh: 我想到的是战时产品管理，对吧？你进入这个环境，我认为……我对在Facebook的那段时间印象深刻的是，真正理解并首先诊断平台上发生的事情需要一种令人敬佩的谦逊。
text_es: Pienso en la gestión de productos en tiempos de guerra, ¿verdad? Estás entrando, y lo que aprecié de esa época en Facebook fue la increíble humildad que se necesitaba para realmente entender y, primero, diagnosticar lo que estaba sucediendo en la plataforma.
context: Lenny asks Alex what it was like leading Facebook's news product immediately after the 2016 presidential election, when Facebook was facing intense criticism over misinformation and disinformation. Alex describes entering a crisis situation where Facebook needed to completely rethink how it handled content on the platform, moving from treating all public content equally to distinguishing between factually accurate journalism and potentially misleading information.
vocabulary_highlights: wartime product management, incredible humility
topics: Product Management, Leadership & Management, Decision Making

speaker: Alex Hardiman
speaker_expertise: Product Strategy, B2B SaaS, Consumer Products
text: I just actually think that that's where product people thrive. The idea of being able to take all of these crazy inputs, trying to create a very structured model to figure out, 'Okay, what is true? Where do we have conviction? Where do we have questions? What are the most important problems to solve? How do you prioritize? How do you get a team rallied around a shared context in one single goal?'
text_ko: 저는 제품 관련 사람들이 바로 그곳에서 잘 성장한다고 생각해요. 다양한 복잡한 정보들을 모아서, '이게 진짜 뭐지? 우리가 확신하는 건 뭐고? 궁금한 점은 뭐지? 해결해야 할 가장 중요한 문제는 무엇인가? 우선순위는 어떻게 정하지? 팀을 하나의 목표를 위해 어떻게 모을 수 있을까?' 같은 구조화된 모델을 만드는 과정이 정말 중요하다고 봐요.
text_zh: 我认为这正是产品经理发挥优势的地方。能够将各种复杂的输入整合起来，构建一个有条理的模型，以弄清楚“什么是真实的？我们在哪些方面有信心？我们有哪些疑问？最重要的问题是什么？如何进行优先级排序？如何让团队围绕一个共同的目标团结起来？”
text_es: Creo que ahí es donde realmente prosperan las personas de producto. La idea de poder tomar todos estos insumos locos y tratar de crear un modelo muy estructurado para determinar: '¿Qué es lo que realmente importa? ¿Dónde tenemos convicción? ¿Dónde tenemos dudas? ¿Cuáles son los problemas más importantes que debemos resolver? ¿Cómo se prioriza? ¿Cómo se logra que un equipo se una en torno a un contexto compartido y un objetivo único?'
context: Lenny observes that Alex seems drawn to chaotic, high-pressure situations and asks what she's learned about working in constant urgency. Alex explains her philosophy that product managers actually perform best in chaotic environments because they excel at organizing complex information, building structured approaches to problems, and getting teams aligned around clear priorities when there's no existing playbook to follow.
vocabulary_highlights: crazy inputs, get a team rallied around
topics: Product Management, Leadership & Management, Decision Making

speaker: Alex Hardiman
speaker_expertise: Product Strategy, B2B SaaS, Consumer Products
text: When we acquired Wordle, it was a simple web game with no backend. That meant that people's stats and streaks, which was that was the value in terms of social currency that people were sharing after playing, those stats and streaks were stored in local browsers.
text_ko: 우리가 Wordle을 인수했을 때, 그건 백엔드도 없는 간단한 웹 게임이었어요. 그래서 사람들이 게임을 한 후에 공유하던 통계와 연속 기록은 로컬 브라우저에 저장되고 있었죠. 그게 바로 사람들이 소셜 커런시(social currency)로 생각했던 가치였어요.
text_zh: 当我们收购Wordle时，它只是一个简单的网页游戏，没有后端。这意味着玩家的统计数据和连胜记录（streaks），即人们在游戏后分享的社交价值，都是存储在本地浏览器中的。
text_es: Cuando adquirimos Wordle, era un juego web simple sin backend. Eso significaba que las estadísticas y las rachas de los jugadores, que eran el valor en términos de moneda social que la gente compartía después de jugar, se almacenaban en los navegadores locales.
context: Alex is explaining the technical challenges of integrating Wordle into The New York Times' platform after they acquired it. She describes how the original game had no database infrastructure, meaning all user progress was saved locally on individual devices. This created problems when people switched devices or browsers, losing their playing history that was important for the social sharing aspect of the game.
vocabulary_highlights: social currency

speaker: Alex Hardiman
speaker_expertise: Product Strategy, B2B SaaS, Consumer Products
text: This was a moment where we just had to come out and really tell the world, 'We're mid integration. We're really not trying to communicate more than Wordle being a fun diversion from the news. Here's what happened, and why.' Everyone understood. This is where coming out being really transparent about the facts and in some cases just exposing more about the product development process really helps demystify some of the rumors that people might otherwise think.
text_ko: 이건 우리가 나와서 세상에 정말로 말해야 했던 순간이에요. '우리는 지금 통합 중이에요. Wordle이 뉴스에서 잠깐 벗어나는 재미있는 오락이라는 걸 더 이상 설명하려고 하지 않아요. 이게 무슨 일이 있었고, 왜 그런지 알려드릴게요.' 모두가 이해했어요. 이렇게 사실에 대해 투명하게 이야기하고, 때로는 제품 개발 과정에 대해 더 많이 공개하는 게 사람들이 가질 수 있는 여러 루머를 불식시키는 데 정말 도움이 돼요.
text_zh: 这是一个我们必须向世界坦诚的时刻，我们正在进行中期整合（mid integration）。我们并不想传达比《Wordle》作为一种有趣的消遣（fun diversion from the news）更多的信息。事情是这样的，原因也在这里。大家都理解。这时，坦诚地公开事实，并在某些情况下更多地揭示产品开发过程，确实有助于澄清人们可能会产生的一些谣言。
text_es: Este fue un momento en el que simplemente teníamos que salir y decirle al mundo: 'Estamos en medio de la integración. Realmente no estamos tratando de comunicar más que Wordle como una divertida distracción de las noticias. Esto es lo que sucedió y por qué.' Todos lo entendieron. Aquí es donde ser realmente transparente sobre los hechos y, en algunos casos, revelar más sobre el proceso de desarrollo del producto ayuda a desmitificar algunos de los rumores que la gente podría pensar de otra manera.
context: Alex describes a crisis that occurred during Wordle's integration when the daily word was 'fetus' on the same day the Supreme Court's Roe v. Wade draft ruling leaked. Due to technical limitations during the migration process, they couldn't change the word for all users, creating an unfortunate coincidence that looked like political commentary. Alex explains how transparency about their technical constraints helped resolve the situation.
vocabulary_highlights: fun diversion, demystify some of the rumors
topics: Product Management, Communication Skills, Decision Making

speaker: Alex Hardiman
speaker_expertise: Product Strategy, B2B SaaS, Consumer Products
text: This is a product leader, it's a real wartime moment where you just need to blow up roadmaps, share context with everyone and say, 'Okay, everyone, we have a totally different mandate than what we did a couple weeks ago.' Given the needs in the world and the mission of the New York Times and our purpose, which is to help people access information to make informed decision about their lives, we're going to do a whole bunch of these things.
text_ko: 이건 제품 리더로서 정말 전시 상황 같은 순간이에요. 로드맵을 완전히 바꿔야 하고, 모든 사람과 상황을 공유하면서 '자, 여러분, 우리는 몇 주 전과는 완전히 다른 임무를 맡게 됐어요.'라고 말해야 해요. 세상의 필요와 뉴욕 타임스의 미션, 즉 사람들이 정보에 접근해서 자신의 삶에 대한 현명한 결정을 내릴 수 있도록 돕는 우리의 목적을 고려할 때, 우리는 이런 것들을 많이 할 거예요.
text_zh: 这是一个产品领导者的真实战时时刻，我们需要彻底重塑路线图，与每个人分享背景，并说：“好吧，大家，我们的任务与几周前完全不同。”鉴于世界的需求以及《纽约时报》的使命和我们的目标，即帮助人们获取信息，以便对他们的生活做出明智的决策，我们将开展一系列新的工作。
text_es: Este es un momento crucial para un líder de producto; es un verdadero momento de crisis en el que es necesario revisar completamente los planes (roadmaps), compartir el contexto con todos y decir: 'Bien, todos, tenemos un mandato totalmente diferente al que teníamos hace un par de semanas.' Dadas las necesidades del mundo y la misión del New York Times, que es ayudar a las personas a acceder a la información para tomar decisiones informadas sobre sus vidas, vamos a llevar a cabo una serie de iniciativas.
context: Alex describes the early days of the COVID-19 pandemic when she had just returned to The New York Times. She explains how the crisis required completely abandoning planned product roadmaps to focus on urgent public health needs. The team pivoted to build COVID tracking databases, data visualization tools, and made critical health information freely available, recognizing their responsibility to serve the public good during a global emergency.
vocabulary_highlights: blow up roadmaps, totally different mandate
topics: Leadership & Management, Product Management, Decision Making

speaker: Alex Hardiman
speaker_expertise: Product Strategy, B2B SaaS, Consumer Products
text: One thing that's really interesting is that our impact and our business goals are in service of our mission, which is to seek the truth and help people understand the world, not the other way around. What it means is that the way that we think about impact is growing a giant subscription business. That business exists to strengthen an informed democracy at a time when people are struggling to understand basic facts and struggling to understand each other.
text_ko: 정말 흥미로운 점은 우리의 영향력과 비즈니스 목표가 우리의 사명, 즉 진실을 추구하고 사람들이 세상을 이해하도록 돕는 데에 있다는 거예요. 반대가 아니라는 거죠. 그래서 우리가 영향력에 대해 생각하는 방식은 거대한 구독 비즈니스를 키우는 거예요. 이 비즈니스는 사람들이 기본적인 사실을 이해하는 데 어려움을 겪고 서로를 이해하는 데 힘든 시기에 정보에 기반한 민주주의를 강화하기 위해 존재하는 거예요.
text_zh: 一个非常有趣的事情是，我们的影响力和商业目标是为了实现我们的使命，即寻求真相并帮助人们理解世界，而不是反过来。这意味着我们对影响力的看法是发展一个庞大的订阅业务。这个业务的存在是为了在一个人们难以理解基本事实和彼此沟通的时代，增强一个知情的民主。
text_es: Una cosa realmente interesante es que nuestro impacto y nuestros objetivos comerciales están al servicio de nuestra misión, que es buscar la verdad y ayudar a las personas a entender el mundo, no al revés. Esto significa que nuestra forma de pensar sobre el impacto se centra en hacer crecer un gran negocio de suscripción. Ese negocio existe para fortalecer una democracia informada en un momento en que las personas tienen dificultades para entender hechos básicos y para comprenderse entre sí.
context: Alex is explaining how The New York Times approaches the concept of impact differently from traditional tech companies. She contrasts their mission-first approach with typical business-first models, emphasizing that their subscription business exists to serve democratic values and public understanding rather than purely commercial objectives. This creates a broader definition of success that includes both financial metrics and societal outcomes.
vocabulary_highlights: in service of, strengthen an informed democracy

speaker: Alex Komoroske
speaker_expertise: Product Strategy, AI/ML Products, Product Management
text: I find that when you're busy, you're constantly just go, go, go, go. There's no time to do any deep thinking. Deep thinking takes time and space, and you got to create that space. The mundane, pointless bullshit will take every square inch you give it. So you got to make that space to sit back and reflect and luxuriate in these ideas.
text_ko: 바쁠 때는 계속해서 움직이기만 하게 되잖아요. 깊이 있는 생각을 할 시간이 없어요. 깊은 생각은 시간과 공간이 필요한데, 그 공간을 만들어야 해요. 쓸데없는 것들이 주어진 모든 공간을 다 차지할 거예요. 그래서 한 발짝 물러나서 생각하고, 이런 아이디어들을 만끽할 수 있는 공간을 만들어야 해요.
text_zh: 我发现当你忙碌时，总是处于不断前进的状态，根本没有时间进行深入思考。深入思考需要时间和空间，而你必须创造这样的空间。那些琐碎无意义的事情会占据你所有的时间。因此，你需要腾出时间来放松、反思，并享受这些想法。
text_es: Encuentro que cuando estás ocupado, estás constantemente en movimiento, sin parar. No hay tiempo para pensar en profundidad. El pensamiento profundo requiere tiempo y espacio, y debes crear ese espacio. Lo trivial y sin sentido ocupará cada centímetro cuadrado que le des. Por lo tanto, es necesario hacer ese espacio para sentarse, reflexionar y disfrutar de estas ideas.
context: Lenny asks Alex about the power of forcing yourself to write and reflect versus not doing so. Alex explains why he dedicates time for deep reflection despite his busy schedule. He describes how he used to work from home on Fridays to avoid meetings and focus on strategic thinking - reading documents carefully and identifying what could have saved time during the week if he had done it beforehand.
vocabulary_highlights: luxuriate in, take every square inch, mundane, pointless bullshit

speaker: Alex Komoroske
speaker_expertise: Product Strategy, AI/ML Products, Product Management
text: I think LLMs are truly a disruptive technology. In fact, I would argue that what we're seeing in the industry is us trying to use mature playbooks from the end stage of the last tech era in one that doesn't really fit yet. To me, LLMs are magical duct tape. They're formed principally by the distilled intuition of all of society into a thing that operates between, a cost structure between human and plain old computing.
text_ko: 저는 LLMs가 정말로 혁신적인 기술이라고 생각해요. 사실, 지금 업계에서 일어나고 있는 일은 우리가 지난 기술 시대의 성숙한 플레이북(playbook)을 사용하려고 하지만, 그게 아직 잘 맞지 않는 상황이라고 주장할 수 있어요. 제게 LLMs는 마법 같은 접착제 같은 존재예요. 이건 사회의 모든 직관이 응축돼서 만들어진 것으로, 인간과 일반 컴퓨팅 사이에서 작동하는 비용 구조를 가지고 있어요.
text_zh: 我认为大型语言模型（LLMs）确实是一项颠覆性技术。事实上，我认为我们在行业中所看到的，正是我们试图在一个尚未完全适应的时代中，使用上一个技术时代末期的成熟策略。对我来说，LLMs就像是神奇的胶带，它们主要是将整个社会的精华直觉凝聚成一种在人工智能与传统计算之间运作的事物。
text_es: Creo que los LLMs (modelos de lenguaje grande) son realmente una tecnología disruptiva.
