De hecho, argumentaría que lo que estamos viendo en la industria es un intento de aplicar manuales (playbooks) maduros de la etapa final de la última era tecnológica en un contexto que aún no se adapta del todo. Para mí, los LLMs son una especie de cinta adhesiva mágica. Se forman principalmente a partir de la intuición destilada de toda la sociedad en algo que opera en un estructura de costos entre lo humano y la computación tradicional.
context: Lenny asks Alex how LLMs and generative AI will change how products are built in the next 3-5 years. Alex argues that LLMs fundamentally disrupt existing assumptions about software development costs and capabilities. He explains that the industry is mistakenly applying old strategies to this new paradigm, comparing LLMs to 'magical duct tape' that bridges human intelligence and traditional computing.
vocabulary_highlights: mature playbooks, magical duct tape, distilled intuition, plain old computing

speaker: Alex Komoroske
speaker_expertise: Product Strategy, AI/ML Products, Product Management
text: In this cacophony, how do you stand out? You stand out by having good taste. I think taste is the most important thing. You have a perspective that is different from the background noise, different from the average and that people find compelling. How do you find your own taste and how do you lean into that taste is, I think, much more important than just generically executing in the way that everybody else could do.
text_ko: 이 혼잡한 세상에서 어떻게 눈에 띌 수 있을까요? 좋은 취향을 갖는 게 중요해요. 저는 취향이 가장 중요한 요소라고 생각해요. 배경 소음과는 다른, 평균과는 다른 시각을 가지고 있어야 사람들이 매력을 느끼죠. 자신의 취향을 어떻게 찾고, 그 취향을 어떻게 살려나가는지가 다른 사람들과 똑같이 행동하는 것보다 훨씬 더 중요하다고 생각해요.
text_zh: 在这喧嚣中，如何让自己脱颖而出？你需要通过良好的品味来实现。我认为品味是最重要的。你要有与背景噪音不同的视角，与普通人不同，并且让人感到吸引。如何找到自己的品味，以及如何充分发挥这种品味，我认为远比简单地以大家都能做到的方式执行要重要得多。
text_es: En esta cacofonía, ¿cómo te destacas? Te destacas teniendo buen gusto. Creo que el gusto es lo más importante. Tienes una perspectiva que es diferente del ruido de fondo, diferente de lo promedio y que la gente encuentra atractiva. Cómo encuentras tu propio gusto y cómo te apoyas en ese gusto es, en mi opinión, mucho más importante que simplemente ejecutar de manera genérica como lo haría cualquier otra persona.
context: Lenny asks about skills product managers should develop as AI changes the landscape. Alex discusses how AI has reduced the cost of information production, creating overwhelming amounts of content. He argues that in this environment of information overload, developing distinctive taste and perspective becomes the key differentiator rather than just executing standard playbooks.
vocabulary_highlights: in this cacophony, background noise, lean into that taste, generically executing
topics: Product Management, Strategy & Planning, Leadership & Management

speaker: Alex Komoroske
speaker_expertise: Product Strategy, AI/ML Products, Product Management
text: So much of the way that we tackle problems and build products is this builder mindset. It's like I have a plan. I then manipulate things to match my plan and make it happen. And this is a way you can create tons of value. Part of the problem though is it can't possibly create more value than the effort that you put into it. What I look for instead are things that can be gardened, things that can grow on their own and that you can direct or maybe give a little bit of extra energy to or curate over, and is a totally different mindset for it.
text_ko: 우리가 문제를 해결하고 제품을 만드는 방식은 '빌더 마인드셋(builder mindset)'이라고 할 수 있어요. 계획을 세우고, 그 계획에 맞게 모든 것을 조정해서 실행하는 거죠. 이렇게 하면 많은 가치를 창출할 수 있어요. 하지만 문제는, 그렇게 해서 만들어낸 가치가 내가 투자한 노력보다 더 클 수는 없다는 거예요. 그래서 제가 찾는 것은 스스로 자랄 수 있는 것들, 즉 '가드닝(gardening)'할 수 있는 것들이에요. 그런 것들은 내가 방향을 잡아주거나 조금 에너지를 더해줄 수 있는 것들이고, 이건 완전히 다른 마인드셋이에요.
text_zh: 我们解决问题和构建产品的方式很大程度上是基于一种建设者心态。就像我有一个计划，然后我调整事物以符合我的计划并使其实现。这是一种可以创造大量价值的方法。然而，问题在于，这种方法所创造的价值不可能超过你投入的努力。我更关注的是那些可以“耕耘”的事物，那些能够自我成长的事物，你可以引导它们，或者给予一点额外的能量去培育，这是一种完全不同的心态。
text_es: Gran parte de la forma en que abordamos problemas y construimos productos se basa en esta mentalidad de constructor. Es como tener un plan, y luego manipular las cosas para que se ajusten a ese plan y hacerlo realidad. Y esta es una manera de crear un gran valor. Sin embargo, parte del problema es que no puede generar más valor del esfuerzo que le dediques. Lo que busco en cambio son cosas que se puedan cultivar, cosas que puedan crecer por sí solas y a las que puedas dirigir o quizás dar un poco de energía extra o curar, lo cual implica una mentalidad totalmente diferente.
context: Alex introduces his core philosophy of 'gardening versus building' as an alternative approach to product development and problem-solving. The builder mindset involves creating detailed plans and forcing execution, while the gardening mindset focuses on nurturing things that can grow organically with minimal intervention. Alex argues this gardening approach can create exponentially more value than the linear effort-to-value relationship of traditional building.
vocabulary_highlights: builder mindset, manipulate things to match, can be gardened, curate over
topics: Product Management, Strategy & Planning, Leadership & Management

speaker: Alex Komoroske
speaker_expertise: Product Strategy, AI/ML Products, Product Management
text: If you do this properly, it looks like magic. I've been told that this is completely against all the advice that people get, including products nowadays, but I think it's a very powerful approach that works in a lot of different contexts. You're farming for miracles. And so on a systemic basis, I can't tell you which of these things will work, but I can tell you there's a very high likelihood that one of these will work in a way that is interesting and transformative.
text_ko: 이걸 제대로 하면 마법처럼 보인대요. 요즘 사람들이 받는 조언이나 제품과는 완전히 반대라고 하더라고요. 하지만 이건 다양한 상황에서 효과가 있는 아주 강력한 접근법이라고 생각해요. 기적을 키우는 거죠. 그래서 어떤 게 효과가 있을지는 확실히 말할 수는 없지만, 이 중 하나는 흥미롭고 변화를 가져올 가능성이 아주 높다는 건 말씀드릴 수 있어요.
text_zh: 如果你正确地做到这一点，它看起来就像魔法。我听说这完全违背了人们得到的所有建议，包括现在的产品，但我认为这是一种在许多不同场景中都非常有效的强大方法。你是在寻找奇迹。因此，从系统的角度来看，我无法告诉你这些方法中哪一个会有效，但我可以告诉你，其中一个很有可能以一种有趣且具有变革性的方式奏效。
text_es: Si lo haces correctamente, parece magia. Me han dicho que esto va en contra de todos los consejos que la gente recibe, incluidos los productos actuales, pero creo que es un enfoque muy poderoso que funciona en muchos contextos diferentes. Estás cultivando milagros. Así que, de manera sistémica, no puedo decirte cuál de estas cosas funcionará, pero puedo asegurarte que hay una alta probabilidad de que alguna de ellas funcione de una manera interesante y transformadora.
context: Lenny asks Alex to elaborate on the gardening versus building concept and provide examples. Alex explains that when you focus on nurturing things with compounding potential rather than forcing predetermined outcomes, the results can appear magical. He describes this as 'farming for miracles' - planting many seeds knowing that while you can't predict which will succeed, the probability is high that at least one will grow into something transformative.
vocabulary_highlights: farming for miracles, on a systemic basis, in a way that is interesting and transformative
topics: Product Management, Strategy & Planning, Leadership & Management

speaker: Alex Komoroske
speaker_expertise: Product Strategy, AI/ML Products, Product Management
text: The kayfabe, the thing that everyone pretends to believe is true, is obviously incorrect. And the dangerous part about this is it can lead you to make very bad decisions. And if you as someone who sees this can see that wait a second, the official strategy is definitely not going to work, you're like, 'I got to tell somebody. We're doing work that's going in a bad direction. It's not going to work.'
text_ko: 사람들이 모두 진짜라고 믿는 것처럼 행동하는 그 가짜 현실(kayfabe)은 분명히 잘못된 거예요. 문제는 이게 나쁜 결정을 내리게 할 수 있다는 거죠. 만약 당신이 이걸 보고 '잠깐, 공식 전략은 분명히 효과가 없겠구나'라고 생각한다면, '누군가에게 말해야 해. 우리가 잘못된 방향으로 가고 있어. 이건 안 될 거야.'라고 느낄 거예요.
text_zh: 这种表象（kayfabe），大家都假装相信的事情，显然是错误的。而这其中的危险在于，它可能导致你做出非常糟糕的决策。如果你作为一个能够看清这一点的人意识到，官方策略显然行不通，你就会想：“我得告诉某个人。我们正在做的工作走上了错误的方向，这样下去是行不通的。”
text_es: El kayfabe, esa idea que todos pretenden creer que es cierta, es claramente incorrecta. Y lo peligroso de esto es que puede llevarte a tomar decisiones muy malas. Si tú, como alguien que se da cuenta de esto, ves que, un momento, la estrategia oficial definitivamente no va a funcionar, piensas: 'Tengo que decírselo a alguien. Estamos trabajando en una dirección equivocada. No va a funcionar.'
context: Lenny asks Alex to explain organizational kayfabe - a concept borrowed from professional wrestling meaning something everyone knows is fake but acts like it's real. Alex describes how small optimistic lies compound up through organizational layers, creating strategies that are obviously flawed but become dangerous to challenge. He explains the dilemma faced by employees who see the truth but risk career damage by speaking up.
vocabulary_highlights: kayfabe, going in a bad direction, hit the ground truth button

speaker: Alexander Embiricos
text: By far, I would say the speed and ambition of working at OpenAI are just dramatically more than what I can imagine. And I guess it's kind of an embarrassing thing to say because everyone who's a startup founder thinks like, "Oh yeah, my startup moves super fast and the talent bar is super high and we're super ambitious." But I have to say, working in OpenAI just made me reimagine what that even means.
text_ko: 솔직히 말하면, OpenAI에서 일하는 속도와 야망은 제가 상상했던 것보다 훨씬 더 대단해요. 스타트업 창립자라면 누구나 "우리 스타트업은 정말 빠르게 움직이고, 인재 수준도 높고, 야망도 엄청나다"고 생각하잖아요. 그런데 OpenAI에서 일하면서 그게 어떤 의미인지 다시 생각하게 됐어요.
text_zh: 我可以说，在OpenAI工作的速度和雄心远远超出了我的想象。我觉得这有点尴尬，因为每个创业公司创始人都认为“哦，我的创业公司发展得非常快，人才标准非常高，我们的雄心也非常大。”但我必须说，在OpenAI的工作让我重新定义了这一切的意义。
text_es: Sin duda, diría que la velocidad y la ambición de trabajar en OpenAI son mucho más de lo que puedo imaginar. Y supongo que es un poco vergonzoso decirlo, porque todos los fundadores de startups piensan: "Oh sí, mi startup se mueve súper rápido, el nivel de talento es muy alto y somos muy ambiciosos." Pero tengo que decir que trabajar en OpenAI me hizo replantear lo que eso realmente significa.
context: Lenny asks Alexander what is most different about how OpenAI operates compared to other places he's worked. Alexander explains that despite having been a startup founder who thought his company moved fast, OpenAI's speed and ambition are on a completely different level that forced him to reimagine what those concepts even mean.
vocabulary_highlights: by far, dramatically more than what I can imagine, embarrassing thing to say, reimagine what that even means

speaker: Alexander Embiricos
text: One of the learnings over the past year is that for models to do stuff, they're much more effective when they can use a computer. It turns out the best way for models to use computers is simply to write code. And so we're kind of getting to this idea where if you want to build any agent, maybe you should be building a coding agent.
text_ko: 지난 1년 동안 배운 것 중 하나는 모델들이 일을 잘 하려면 컴퓨터를 활용하는 게 훨씬 효과적이라는 거예요. 결국 모델들이 컴퓨터를 잘 활용하는 방법은 코드를 작성하는 거더라고요. 그래서 이제는 어떤 에이전트를 만들고 싶다면, 코딩 에이전트를 만드는 게 좋지 않을까 하는 생각이 드는 것 같아요.
text_zh: 过去一年中的一个重要经验是，模型在执行任务时，能够使用计算机会更加高效。事实证明，模型使用计算机的最佳方式就是编写代码。因此，我们逐渐形成了这样的观点：如果你想构建任何智能体，或许应该考虑构建一个编码智能体。
text_es: Una de las lecciones del año pasado es que para que los modelos sean efectivos, es mucho mejor que puedan utilizar una computadora. Resulta que la mejor manera para que los modelos usen computadoras es simplemente escribiendo código. Así que estamos llegando a la idea de que si quieres construir algún agente, tal vez deberías estar construyendo un agente de programación (coding agent).
context: Lenny asks Alexander how he thinks OpenAI will win in the AI coding space. Alexander explains his vision for building a super assistant that can take actions in the world. He argues that the most effective way for AI models to use computers and accomplish tasks is through writing code, leading to the insight that all useful agents should fundamentally be coding agents.
vocabulary_highlights: turns out, we're kind of getting to this idea

speaker: Alexander Embiricos
text: A few of us are constantly on Reddit. There's praise up there and there's a lot of complaints. What we can do is as a product team just try to always think about how are we building a tool so that it feels like we're maximally accelerating people rather than building a tool that makes it more unclear what you should do as the human?
text_ko: 우리 몇 명은 항상 Reddit을 확인해요. 거기에는 칭찬도 많고 불만도 많죠. 우리가 제품 팀으로서 할 수 있는 건, 사람들이 최대한 빠르게 성장할 수 있도록 도와주는 도구를 어떻게 만들지 항상 고민하는 거예요. 인간이 해야 할 일이 더 불분명해지는 도구를 만드는 게 아니라요.
text_zh: 我们团队中的一些人经常在Reddit上浏览。那里有很多赞扬，也有不少抱怨。作为产品团队，我们需要始终思考如何构建一个工具，让用户感受到我们在最大程度上加速他们的工作，而不是让他们对该做什么感到更加困惑。
text_es: Algunos de nosotros estamos constantemente en Reddit. Allí hay elogios y muchas quejas. Lo que podemos hacer como equipo de producto es siempre pensar en cómo estamos construyendo una herramienta que haga sentir a los usuarios que los estamos impulsando al máximo, en lugar de desarrollar una herramienta que genere más confusión sobre lo que deben hacer como personas.
context: Lenny asks Alexander how they measure progress on Codex and what metrics they focus on. Alexander explains that beyond traditional metrics, his team actively monitors social media platforms like Reddit to gather user feedback. He emphasizes their philosophy of building tools that maximize human acceleration rather than creating confusion about the human's role.
vocabulary_highlights: maximally accelerating, makes it more unclear

speaker: Alexander Embiricos
text: One of the most mind-blowing examples of acceleration, the Sora Android app, like a fully new app, we built it in 18 days and then 10 days later, so 28 days total, we went to the public.
text_ko: 가장 놀라운 가속화의 예 중 하나인 Sora 안드로이드 앱은 완전히 새로운 앱처럼, 우리는 18일 만에 만들었고, 그 후 10일이 지나서 총 28일 만에 공개했어요.
text_zh: Sora Android 应用是加速的一个令人震惊的例子，我们在18天内完成了这个全新的应用，10天后，也就是总共28天，我们就向公众发布了。
text_es: Uno de los ejemplos más sorprendentes de aceleración, la aplicación Sora para Android, como si fuera una aplicación completamente nueva, la desarrollamos en 18 días y luego, 10 días después, en total 28 días, la lanzamos al público.
context: Alexander is describing the impressive capabilities of Codex in accelerating software development at OpenAI. He shares a concrete example of how Codex enabled the team to build and ship the Sora Android app - which became the number one app in the app store - in just 28 days total, demonstrating the dramatic speed improvements possible with AI coding assistance.
vocabulary_highlights: mind-blowing examples, went to the public

speaker: Alexander Embiricos
text: I think there's constantly these levels of abstraction and they're actually already played out today. Today, coding agents, mostly it's prompt to patch. We're starting to see people doing spec-driven development or planned and driven development.
text_ko: 지금은 계속해서 다양한 추상화 수준이 존재하는 것 같아요. 오늘날에는 주로 프롬프트를 패치하는 방식으로 코딩 에이전트들이 활용되고 있죠. 요즘에는 스펙 기반 개발(spec-driven development)이나 계획 기반 개발(planned and driven development)을 하는 사람들도 점점 늘어나고 있어요.
text_zh: 我认为在不断地存在这些抽象层次，而这些层次实际上已经在今天得到了体现。目前，编码代理主要是通过提示进行修补。我们开始看到人们在进行规范驱动开发（spec-driven development）或计划驱动开发（planned and driven development）。
text_es: Creo que constantemente existen estos niveles de abstracción que ya se están manifestando hoy en día. Actualmente, los agentes de codificación, en su mayoría, se basan en prompts para realizar parches. Estamos comenzando a ver a personas que practican el desarrollo basado en especificaciones (spec-driven development) o el desarrollo planificado y orientado (planned and driven development).
context: Lenny asks Alexander about the future of software development, specifically whether engineers will move to higher abstraction levels like spec-driven development rather than writing actual code. Alexander explains that these abstraction levels are already emerging, with current coding agents evolving from simple prompt-to-patch workflows to more sophisticated spec-driven and plan-driven development approaches.
vocabulary_highlights: levels of abstraction, played out, prompt to patch, spec-driven development

speaker: Alexander Embiricos
text: The current underappreciated limiting factor is literally human typing speed or human multitasking speed.
text_ko: 현재 간과되고 있는 제한 요소는 사실상 사람의 타이핑 속도나 멀티태스킹 속도예요.
text_zh: 当前被低估的限制因素实际上是人类的打字速度或多任务处理速度。
text_es: El factor limitante que actualmente se subestima es, en realidad, la velocidad de tecleo humano o la velocidad de multitarea humana.
context: Lenny asks Alexander about his AGI timeline and how far we are from artificial general intelligence. Alexander shares his unique perspective that one of the biggest bottlenecks to achieving AGI-level productivity isn't the AI capabilities themselves, but rather human limitations in typing prompts and reviewing AI-generated work fast enough to keep up with AI's potential output.
vocabulary_highlights: underappreciated limiting factor, multitasking speed

speaker: Alisa Cohn
text: They're trying now to be the leader who everyone loves, but what really needs to happen very often is, we need to drive towards results. This employee continuing to not really do a great job at their job, you don't want to push them because you don't want to upset them. You don't want to give them difficult feedback, so you're just going to keep hoping it works out. Ultimately, that leads to the demise of your company.
text_ko: 지금 모두가 사랑하는 리더가 되려고 노력하고 있지만, 사실 우리가 정말로 해야 하는 것은 결과를 이끌어내는 거예요. 이 직원이 계속해서 일을 잘 하지 못하는데, 그 사람을 밀어붙이기 싫어서 힘든 피드백을 주지 않으려는 경우가 많죠. 그래서 그냥 잘 되길 바라는 것만으로는 안 돼요. 결국, 이런 태도가 회사의 몰락으로 이어질 수 있어요.
text_zh: 他们现在试图成为大家都喜欢的领导，但实际上更需要的是，我们必须专注于结果。这个员工在工作中表现不佳，你不想给他们施加压力，因为你不想让他们不高兴。你也不想给他们带来困难的反馈，因此你只是希望事情能好转。最终，这会导致公司的衰败。
text_es: Están tratando de ser el líder que todos aman, pero lo que realmente necesita suceder con frecuencia es que debemos enfocarnos en los resultados. Este empleado que sigue sin desempeñar bien su trabajo, no quieres presionarlo porque no quieres molestarlo. No quieres darle retroalimentación difícil, así que simplemente seguirás esperando que las cosas se resuelvan. En última instancia, eso lleva a la caída de tu empresa.
context: Lenny asks Alisa about her advice that a leader's job is not to make employees happy. Alisa explains that many founders and leaders, especially those new to management, mistakenly prioritize keeping everyone happy over driving business results. She describes how this misguided approach leads to avoiding difficult conversations and performance issues, ultimately harming the company's success.
vocabulary_highlights: drive towards results, demise of your company, hoping it works out

speaker: Alisa Cohn
text: Hope for the future is so important. I know this is going to be challenging for you to hear, not going to promote you, but I want you to know this. It's really important to me that you're able to succeed in your career here, and so I want to continue to help you find opportunities to build your skills and to advance.
text_ko: 미래에 대한 희망은 정말 중요해요. 이 말을 듣기 힘들 수도 있다는 걸 알아요. 승진은 없겠지만, 이 점은 꼭 알고 있었으면 해요. 당신이 여기서 경력을 쌓는 게 저에게 정말 중요하고, 그래서 계속해서 당신이 기술을 쌓고 발전할 수 있는 기회를 찾는 데 도와주고 싶어요.
text_zh: 对未来的希望非常重要。我知道这对你来说可能很难接受，我不会给你晋升，但我希望你明白这一点。对我来说，你在这里的职业成功非常重要，因此我希望继续帮助你寻找机会，以提升你的技能和职业发展。
text_es: La esperanza en el futuro es fundamental. Sé que esto puede ser difícil de escuchar, no te voy a promover, pero quiero que lo sepas. Me importa mucho que puedas tener éxito en tu carrera aquí, y por eso quiero seguir ayudándote a encontrar oportunidades para desarrollar tus habilidades y avanzar.
context: Lenny asks Alisa for advice on having difficult conversations during performance review season, specifically when telling someone they won't get a promotion they expected. Alisa provides a script for delivering this disappointing news while maintaining hope and showing care for the employee's future development. She emphasizes the importance of painting a path forward rather than just delivering bad news.
vocabulary_highlights: hope for the future, challenging for you to hear
topics: Communication Skills, Leadership & Management, Career Development

speaker: Alisa Cohn
text: What I want to say to everybody is, sometimes you need to have patience and sometimes you need to look at the process. And I think you, as the leader, need to have the wisdom to know the difference, but also your finger on the pulse to recognize, is this an issue with patience or an issue with process?
text_ko: 제가 여러분에게 하고 싶은 말은, 가끔은 인내심이 필요하고, 가끔은 과정을 살펴봐야 한다는 거예요. 그리고 리더로서 여러분은 그 차이를 아는 지혜가 필요하다고 생각해요. 동시에 상황을 잘 파악해서, 이게 인내심의 문제인지 아니면 과정의 문제인지 알아차리는 것도 중요해요.
text_zh: 我想对大家说的是，有时候需要耐心，有时候需要关注过程。作为领导者，我认为你需要具备智慧来分辨两者的不同，同时也要时刻关注情况，以识别这是耐心的问题还是过程的问题。
text_es: Lo que quiero decirles a todos es que a veces es necesario tener paciencia y otras veces hay que enfocarse en el proceso. Creo que, como líder, es fundamental tener la sabiduría para saber la diferencia, pero también estar atento para reconocer si se trata de un problema de paciencia o de proceso.
context: Alisa shares a story about working with a CEO whose product launch kept getting delayed. The CEO believed he needed patience, but Alisa discovered underlying process problems involving an inexperienced product manager and team conflicts. She emphasizes that leaders must distinguish between situations requiring patience versus those needing process intervention, and stay close enough to operations to make this critical distinction.
vocabulary_highlights: finger on the pulse, wisdom to know the difference
topics: Leadership & Management, Decision Making, Strategy & Planning

speaker: Alisa Cohn
text: My three questions to end the meeting are, what did we decide here? Who needs to do what by when? And who else needs to know? And if you can capture those, articulate those as deliverables, I promise you, you're going to have better meetings.
text_ko: 회의를 마치기 전에 제가 묻고 싶은 세 가지 질문이 있어요. 우리가 여기서 무엇을 결정했나요? 누가 언제까지 무엇을 해야 하나요? 그리고 누가 더 알아야 하나요? 이 내용을 잘 정리해서 전달할 수 있다면, 분명 더 나은 회의를 가질 수 있을 거예요.
text_zh: 我结束会议的三个问题是：我们在这里达成了什么决定？谁需要在什么时候完成什么？还有谁需要了解这些？如果你能记录下这些内容，并将其明确为可交付成果，我保证你会有更高效的会议。
text_es: Mis tres preguntas para cerrar la reunión son: ¿qué decidimos aquí? ¿Quién necesita hacer qué y para cuándo? ¿Y quién más debe estar informado? Si puedes capturar eso y articularlo como entregables (deliverables), te prometo que tendrás reuniones más efectivas.
context: Lenny asks Alisa about her advice for making meetings more effective. Alisa explains that many meetings fail because there's no continuity between sessions - teams keep re-meeting and re-deciding the same issues. Her three-question framework ensures meetings end with clear outcomes, accountability, and communication plans, preventing the common problem of endless unproductive meeting cycles.
vocabulary_highlights: articulate those as deliverables
topics: Communication Skills, Leadership & Management, Strategy & Planning

speaker: Alisa Cohn
text: According to Noam, Noam Wasserstein, 65% of startups fail because of conflict with founders or the founding team. So it's really essential to get this right, and I agree that people step into this relationship with a lot less care than they should.
text_ko: 노암 워서스타인(Noam Wasserstein)에 따르면, 스타트업의 65%가 창립자나 창립 팀과의 갈등 때문에 실패한다고 해요. 그래서 이 부분을 제대로 챙기는 게 정말 중요해요. 사람들이 이 관계에 대해 생각보다 덜 신경 쓰고 시작하는 것 같아요.
text_zh: 根据诺姆·瓦瑟斯坦（Noam Wasserstein）的说法，65%的初创企业因创始人或创始团队之间的冲突而失败。因此，妥善处理这种关系至关重要。我也同意，人们在进入这种关系时往往缺乏应有的谨慎。
text_es: Según Noam Wasserstein, el 65% de las startups fracasan debido a conflictos entre los fundadores o el equipo fundador. Por lo tanto, es fundamental acertar en esto, y estoy de acuerdo en que las personas entran en esta relación con mucho menos cuidado del que deberían.
context: Lenny introduces Alisa's concept of the 'founder prenup' - a set of questions potential co-founders should discuss before starting a company together. Alisa provides the statistical context showing that founder conflicts are a major cause of startup failure. She emphasizes that people enter co-founder relationships too casually, without doing the necessary work to understand each other's values, goals, and working styles.
vocabulary_highlights: step into this relationship, lot less care than they should
topics: Starting a Company, Leadership & Management, Decision Making

speaker: Alisa Cohn
text: I got onto the floor, my hardwood floors in my Brookline condo, and I just balled in the fetal position. I just balled and balled and balled for an hour. It wasn't 10 minutes, it was an hour. And I was so frightened and just upset. Am I going to be able to make this work?
text_ko: 저는 브룩라인 콘도의 나무 바닥에 무릎을 꿇고 fetal position(태아 자세)으로 웅크리고 있었어요. 한 시간 동안 계속 울었어요. 10분이 아니라 정말 한 시간 동안이었죠. 너무 무섭고 속상했어요. 이걸 잘 해낼 수 있을까?
text_zh: 我躺在布鲁克莱恩公寓的木地板上，蜷缩成 fetal position（胎儿姿势），哭了整整一个小时。不是十分钟，而是一个小时。我感到非常害怕和沮丧。我能否让这一切成功呢？
text_es: Me tiré al suelo, en el piso de madera de mi condominio en Brookline, y simplemente me acurruqué en posición fetal. Lloré y lloré durante una hora. No fueron 10 minutos, fueron una hora. Estaba tan asustado y molesto. ¿Voy a poder hacer que esto funcione?
context: During the 'Fail Corner' segment, Lenny asks Alisa to share a personal failure story. Alisa describes a rock bottom moment when she was starting her coaching practice and had a conversation that didn't go well. She shares her vulnerable moment of crying on the floor for an hour, questioning whether she could make her business work, before eventually picking herself up and continuing to take action.
vocabulary_highlights: balled in the fetal position, rock bottom moment

speaker: Ami Vora
text: I really enjoy being right and then it turns out in the working world, that did not serve me so great. I think the hard part is sublimating your ego a little bit and saying it's more important to get to the outcome than to be right.
text_ko: 저는 맞는 게 정말 좋았는데, 일하는 세상에서는 그게 그렇게 도움이 되지 않았어요. 어려운 부분은 자존심을 조금 내려놓고, 맞는 것보다 결과를 내는 게 더 중요하다는 걸 인정하는 거예요.
text_zh: 我很喜欢自己是对的，但在职场中，这并没有给我带来太大的帮助。我认为困难之处在于要稍微抑制自己的自我，意识到达成结果比证明自己是对的更重要。
text_es: Realmente disfruto tener razón, pero en el mundo laboral, eso no siempre me ha servido de mucho. Creo que lo difícil es sublimar un poco el ego y reconocer que es más importante alcanzar el resultado que tener razón.
context: Lenny shares a quote from Boz (Meta's CTO) about Ami's ability to respond with curiosity when faced with profound disagreements. Ami explains that her natural tendency to always be right didn't work well in professional settings. She had to learn to prioritize getting to the best outcome rather than being the person who's always right, which required setting aside her ego and being open to learning from others' perspectives.
vocabulary_highlights: did not serve me so great, sublimating your ego

speaker: Ami Vora
text: If we all agree that the feeling of something should be, I'm sitting in Dolores Park with my friends on a sunny Saturday, then people will just naturally build something that feels more consistent.
text_ko: 모두가 어떤 느낌이 있어야 한다고 동의한다면, 나는 친구들과 함께 화창한 토요일에 돌로레스 파크에 앉아 있을 거예요. 그러면 사람들은 자연스럽게 더 일관된 느낌을 주는 뭔가를 만들게 될 거예요.
text_zh: 如果我们都认同某种感觉应该是这样的，比如在阳光明媚的星期六，我和朋友们坐在多洛雷斯公园，那么人们自然会创造出更一致的东西。
text_es: Si todos estamos de acuerdo en que la sensación de algo debería ser, como estar sentado en el Parque Dolores con mis amigos en un sábado soleado, entonces las personas naturalmente crearán algo que se sienta más coherente.
context: Ami is discussing how to use metaphors and imagery to rally teams around a shared vision. She explains that when teams agree on a specific feeling or metaphor for their product - in this case, the relaxed, friendly atmosphere of hanging out with friends in a San Francisco park - it guides design and product decisions naturally without needing detailed specifications for every choice.
vocabulary_highlights: just naturally build

speaker: Ami Vora
text: For me, the hill climb is all about the difference between a local optimum and a global optimum. You're standing on top of the hill, you're looking down, you can see rolling hills, the sheep, the grass, whatever, but then, way off in the distance you can see a mountain. And the thing that gets me through the valley is remembering what the summit feels like.
text_ko: 저한테 언덕 오르기는 지역 최적(local optimum)과 전역 최적(global optimum)의 차이에 대한 거예요. 언덕 꼭대기에 서서 아래를 내려다보면 구불구불한 언덕들과 양들, 풀들이 보이죠. 그런데 멀리 산이 보이기도 해요. 제가 계곡을 지나갈 때 버티게 해주는 건 꼭대기에서 느꼈던 그 기분을 기억하는 거예요.
text_zh: 对我来说，爬坡的过程在于局部最优（local optimum）和全局最优（global optimum）之间的差异。你站在山顶，俯瞰四周，可以看到起伏的山丘、羊群、草地等等，但在远处你能看到一座高山。让我穿越山谷的动力，就是时刻记住山顶的感觉。
text_es: Para mí, la subida a la colina se trata de la diferencia entre un óptimo local y un óptimo global. Estás en la cima de la colina, mirando hacia abajo, puedes ver colinas onduladas, ovejas, el pasto, lo que sea, pero luego, a lo lejos, puedes ver una montaña. Y lo que me ayuda a atravesar el valle es recordar cómo se siente estar en la cumbre.
context: Lenny asks Ami about her hill climb metaphor. Ami explains this metaphor represents the challenge of leaving a good situation (local optimum) to pursue something much better (global optimum). The hill climb describes the difficult decision of giving up current success to cross an uncertain valley and climb a higher mountain, with the understanding that remembering the potential reward helps sustain you through the difficult transition period.
vocabulary_highlights: local optimum, global optimum, way off in the distance

speaker: Ami Vora
text: I think the hard part is just sublimating your ego a little bit and saying it's more important to get to the outcome than to be right. And I think all of growth is a battle with yourself, but this is one of the hardest ones because we all want to be right, we all want to protect ourselves.
text_ko: 저는 힘든 부분이 자기 자아를 조금 내려놓고 결과를 얻는 게 옳은 것보다 더 중요하다는 걸 인정하는 거라고 생각해요. 성장이라는 건 결국 자기 자신과의 싸움인데, 이게 가장 어려운 싸움 중 하나인 것 같아요. 왜냐하면 우리 모두 옳고 싶어하고, 자신을 보호하고 싶어하니까요.
text_zh: 我认为最困难的部分就是稍微放下自己的自我，意识到达成结果比证明自己正确更重要。我觉得成长的过程就是与自己斗争，而这其中最难的就是我们都希望自己是对的，都想保护自己。
text_es: Creo que la parte difícil es sublimar un poco tu ego y reconocer que es más importante alcanzar el resultado que tener la razón. Y creo que todo el crecimiento es una lucha contigo mismo, pero esta es una de las más difíciles porque todos queremos tener la razón, todos queremos protegernos.
context: Lenny asks Ami for practical advice on how to disagree skillfully and respond with curiosity like Boz described. Ami explains that the core challenge is managing your ego and prioritizing collective success over personal validation. She emphasizes that personal growth fundamentally involves internal struggles, and the desire to be right is one of the most difficult impulses to overcome because it's tied to our natural self-protective instincts.
vocabulary_highlights: sublimating your ego, battle with yourself

speaker: Ami Vora
text: I think we misuse product reviews sometimes as ways to get decisions and actually, they should be ways to calibrate on principles. So what you don't want is to come to a product review for every single that you want to make.
text_ko: 가끔 제품 리뷰를 결정을 내리는 수단으로 잘못 활용하는 경우가 있는 것 같아요. 사실 제품 리뷰는 원칙을 조율하는 방법이어야 해요. 그래서 매번 모든 결정에 대해 제품 리뷰를 하러 가는 건 피해야 해요.
text_zh: 我认为我们有时错误地使用产品评审作为决策的依据，实际上它们应该是用来校准原则的工具。因此，我们不希望每次做决策时都依赖于产品评审。
text_es: Creo que a veces hacemos un mal uso de las revisiones de productos como una forma de tomar decisiones, cuando en realidad deberían servir para calibrar principios. Lo que no queremos es acudir a una revisión de producto por cada decisión que queremos tomar.
context: Lenny asks Ami for additional advice about running effective product reviews beyond keeping them simple and having recommendations. Ami explains that product reviews are often used incorrectly as decision-making forums when they should actually be used to establish consistent principles. Instead of seeking approval for every individual decision, teams should use reviews to align on decision-making frameworks that enable autonomous choices in the future.
vocabulary_highlights: misuse product reviews, calibrate on principles

speaker: Ami Vora
text: I think execution eats strategy for breakfast and that's something we used to say a lot at Meta. It was just the most important part and I was well-trained in that. That was one of the key lessons that I learned there, and it's because when you have... Look, strategy is super fun. You get to think about all this pie in the sky stuff.
text_ko: 실행이 전략을 아침으로 먹는다고 생각해요. 메타에서 자주 하던 말이었죠. 그게 가장 중요한 부분이었고, 저는 그 부분에 대해 잘 훈련받았어요. 거기서 배운 핵심 교훈 중 하나였죠. 전략은 정말 재미있어요. 온갖 멋진 아이디어를 생각해볼 수 있으니까요.
text_zh: 我认为执行力（execution）胜过战略（strategy），这是我们在Meta常常提到的一点。这是最重要的部分，而我在这方面受过良好的训练。这是我在那里学到的关键教训之一，因为当你拥有……你看，战略确实很有趣。你可以思考很多理想化的事情。
text_es: Creo que la ejecución se come la estrategia para el desayuno, y eso es algo que solíamos decir mucho en Meta. Era la parte más importante y yo estaba bien entrenado en eso. Esa fue una de las lecciones clave que aprendí allí, y es porque cuando tienes... Mira, la estrategia es muy divertida. Puedes pensar en todas estas ideas grandiosas.
context: Lenny brings up Ami's belief that execution beats strategy every time, asking her to elaborate on this philosophy. Ami explains this was a core lesson from Meta, emphasizing that while strategy is intellectually engaging and allows for big-picture thinking, customers only experience the actual product in their hands. She argues that focusing too much on abstract strategic planning can distract from solving real customer problems today.
vocabulary_highlights: execution eats strategy for breakfast, pie in the sky stuff

speaker: Amjad Masad
text: Typically, you're bottlenecked where your ideas are not fitting in because they need to be made and they need to be made quickly. Now, you open up that bottleneck. So now actually making things is a lot easier. Actually, you become limited by how fast you can generate ideas.
text_ko: 보통 아이디어가 잘 맞지 않아서 막히는 경우가 많아요. 그 아이디어를 빨리 만들어야 하는데 말이죠. 이제 그 막힘을 없애면 실제로 만드는 게 훨씬 쉬워져요. 그러니까 이제는 아이디어를 얼마나 빨리 낼 수 있는지가 제한이 되는 거예요.
text_zh: 通常情况下，你会在想法无法适应的地方遇到瓶颈，因为这些想法需要被实现，并且需要快速实现。现在，你打破了这个瓶颈。因此，实际制作东西变得容易多了。实际上，你的限制变成了你生成想法的速度。
text_es: Normalmente, te encuentras en un punto crítico (bottleneck) cuando tus ideas no encajan porque necesitan ser realizadas y de manera rápida. Ahora, al abrir ese punto crítico, hacer las cosas se vuelve mucho más fácil. De hecho, te limitas por la rapidez con la que puedes generar ideas.
context: Lenny asks Amjad about what skills will matter more or less for product managers and founders as AI changes how products are built. Amjad explains that traditionally, people with ideas face a bottleneck when those ideas need to be turned into actual products, which requires technical implementation. With AI tools like Replit making software development much easier and faster, this bottleneck is removed, shifting the limitation from technical execution to idea generation speed.
vocabulary_highlights: bottlenecked, not fitting in, open up that bottleneck, limited by
topics: Product Management, Starting a Company, Strategy & Planning

speaker: Amjad Masad
text: I could imagine whatever five years from now, someone running a billion-dollar company with zero employees where it's like the support is handled by AI, the development is handled by AI, and you're just building and creating this thing.
text_ko: 5년 후에는 직원이 하나도 없는 10억 달러짜리 회사를 운영하는 모습이 상상이 가요. 지원도 AI가 처리하고, 개발도 AI가 맡아서, 그냥 그걸 만들고 창조하는 것만 하는 거죠.
text_zh: 我可以想象五年后，会有人经营一家市值十亿美元的公司，完全没有员工，所有的支持和开发都由人工智能（AI）处理，而你只是专注于构建和创造这个项目。
text_es: Puedo imaginar que en cinco años, alguien esté dirigiendo una empresa de mil millones de dólares sin empleados, donde el soporte sea gestionado por inteligencia artificial, el desarrollo también por inteligencia artificial, y tú simplemente estés construyendo y creando este proyecto.
context: Lenny comments that people are unaware of how far AI development has progressed. Amjad responds by painting a picture of the near future where AI capabilities could reach the point where all traditional business functions could be automated. He envisions a scenario where customer support, software development, and other core business operations are entirely handled by AI, leaving the founder to focus purely on vision and creation.
vocabulary_highlights: whatever five years from now, zero employees, handled by AI
topics: Starting a Company, Leadership & Management, Strategy & Planning

speaker: Amjad Masad
text: One of the reasons for the difficulty is that it is very fragmented, so you would need to download what's called an IDE. It's basically a code editor. You need to download the runtime, basically Python or JavaScript, need to figure out a package manager to configure your kind of open source packages, and once you've done all of that, you need to figure out how to deploy it, how to share it.
text_ko: 어려운 이유 중 하나는 너무 분산되어 있어서, IDE라고 하는 걸 다운로드해야 해요. 기본적으로 코드 편집기 같은 거예요. 그리고 런타임도 다운로드해야 하는데, 보통 Python이나 JavaScript 같은 거죠. 오픈 소스 패키지를 설정할 패키지 매니저도 알아내야 하고, 그 모든 걸 다 한 다음에는 배포하는 방법, 공유하는 방법도 알아내야 해요.
text_zh: 其中一个困难的原因是这个领域非常分散，因此你需要下载一个称为IDE（集成开发环境）的工具。它基本上是一个代码编辑器。你还需要下载运行时环境，基本上是Python或JavaScript，并且需要弄清楚一个包管理器（package manager）来配置你的开源包。一旦完成这些，你还需要弄清楚如何部署（deploy）以及如何分享（share）它。
text_es: Una de las razones de la dificultad es que está muy fragmentado, por lo que necesitarías descargar lo que se llama un IDE (entorno de desarrollo integrado). Básicamente, es un editor de código. Necesitas descargar el runtime, que puede ser Python o JavaScript, y averiguar un gestor de paquetes para configurar tus paquetes de código abierto. Una vez que hayas hecho todo eso, tendrás que descubrir cómo implementarlo y cómo compartirlo.
context: Lenny asks Amjad to explain what Replit is and what problem it solves. Amjad explains that traditional software development is extremely difficult because it requires managing many separate tools and processes. He breaks down the technical barriers that prevent people from learning to code, including setting up development environments, managing dependencies, and deploying applications - all of which Replit aims to simplify into one unified platform.
vocabulary_highlights: very fragmented, package manager, open source packages

speaker: Amjad Masad
text: What gets me excited is a lot of these CEOs are building the future concept, the next product they're going to build, the next, say, company they're going to build. And so it unlocks the creativity and again, sort of unblocks them from that.
text_ko: 저를 신나게 하는 건 많은 CEO들이 미래의 개념이나 다음에 만들 제품, 혹은 다음에 만들 회사를 구상하고 있다는 거예요. 그래서 그게 창의력을 발휘하게 하고, 다시 막힌 걸 뚫어주는 것 같아요.
text_zh: 让我感到兴奋的是，许多首席执行官正在构建未来的概念、他们将要开发的下一个产品，以及他们将要创办的下一个公司。这激发了他们的创造力，并帮助他们打破了思维的障碍。
text_es: Lo que me entusiasma es que muchos de estos CEOs están construyendo el concepto del futuro, el próximo producto que van a desarrollar, la próxima, digamos, empresa que van a crear. Esto desbloquea la creatividad y, de alguna manera, los libera de esas limitaciones.
context: Lenny asks about how non-technical people within startups and companies are using Replit. Amjad describes how CEOs and founders, who are often creative visionaries but lack coding skills, are using the platform. Previously, these leaders were bottlenecked by having to communicate their ideas through other people who then had to build them, but now they can directly prototype and test their future product concepts.
vocabulary_highlights: unlocks the creativity, unblocks them from that
topics: Starting a Company, Leadership & Management, Strategy & Planning

speaker: Amjad Masad
text: I think a very important scale that's perhaps harder to develop but it's worth working on is being generative, being more generative, being able to generate new ideas quickly, because you can think about it as a factory line.
text_ko: 생산적인 능력을 키우는 게 정말 중요하다고 생각해요. 새로운 아이디어를 빠르게 만들어내는 게 쉽지는 않지만, 그만한 가치가 있어요. 마치 공장 라인처럼 생각해볼 수 있죠.
text_zh: 我认为一个非常重要的能力是创造性，尽管这可能更难培养，但值得我们去努力。这种能力能够快速产生新想法，可以把它看作是一条生产线。
text_es: Creo que una escala muy importante que quizás sea más difícil de desarrollar, pero que vale la pena trabajar, es ser generativo, ser más generativo, y poder generar nuevas ideas rápidamente, porque se puede pensar en ello como una línea de producción.
context: Lenny asks what skills product managers, engineers, or designers should focus on more as AI tools become more powerful. Amjad emphasizes that the most crucial skill to develop is being 'generative' - the ability to rapidly come up with new ideas. He uses a factory line metaphor where ideas are the input, production is the middle step, and consumption is the output, explaining that AI removes the production bottleneck.
vocabulary_highlights: being generative, factory line
topics: Career Development, Strategy & Planning, Learning & Growth

speaker: Amjad Masad
text: I have this that's been called not by me, dubbed as Amjad's Law, which is the return on investment for learn to code is doubling every six months. And really just learning a little bit of that skill, learning a bit of skill about how to prompt AI, how to read code, and be able to debug it.
text_ko: 제가 '암자드의 법칙(Amjad's Law)'이라고 부르는 게 있는데요, 코딩을 배우는 데 투자한 수익이 매 6개월마다 두 배로 늘어난다는 거예요. 사실, 그 기술을 조금만 배우면, AI를 어떻게 활용하는지, 코드를 읽는 방법, 그리고 디버깅하는 방법을 익힐 수 있어요.
text_zh: 我有一个被称为阿姆贾德法则（Amjad's Law）的观点，认为学习编程的投资回报率每六个月翻一番。实际上，只需掌握一些相关技能，比如如何与人工智能（AI）进行有效对话、阅读代码和调试代码，就能获得显著的收益。
text_es: Tengo algo que se ha denominado, no por mí, como la Ley de Amjad, que establece que el retorno de inversión (ROI) por aprender a programar se duplica cada seis meses. En realidad, solo aprender un poco de esa habilidad, como cómo interactuar con la inteligencia artificial (IA), leer código y ser capaz de depurarlo, puede marcar una gran diferencia.
context: Amjad continues explaining what skills people should develop in the AI era. He introduces 'Amjad's Law' - his observation that the value of basic coding knowledge is exponentially increasing as AI tools become more powerful. Rather than traditional computer science education, he advocates for learning AI-native skills like prompting, code reading, and debugging to effectively collaborate with AI development tools.
vocabulary_highlights: dubbed as, return on investment, doubling every six months

speaker: Amjad Masad
text: The way we work is going to change rapidly, and it's important to be resilient to that change. One thing that I think is really difficult now is having roadmaps, especially if you're doing anything in AI, but really anything that AI could affect, you want to be able to react to it really quickly.
text_ko: 우리가 일하는 방식이 빠르게 변할 거예요. 그래서 그 변화에 잘 적응하는 게 중요해요. 요즘 특히 어려운 점은 로드맵을 만드는 거예요. AI와 관련된 일을 하든, AI가 영향을 미칠 수 있는 어떤 일이든, 정말 빠르게 반응할 수 있어야 해요.
text_zh: 我们的工作方式将迅速改变，适应这种变化至关重要。我认为现在特别困难的一点是制定路线图（roadmaps），尤其是在人工智能（AI）领域，实际上任何可能受到人工智能影响的领域，都需要能够快速做出反应。
text_es: La forma en que trabajamos va a cambiar rápidamente, y es importante ser resilientes ante ese cambio. Una de las cosas que considero realmente difícil en este momento es tener hojas de ruta (roadmaps), especialmente si estás trabajando en inteligencia artificial (AI), pero en realidad, cualquier cosa que la inteligencia artificial pueda afectar requiere que puedas reaccionar con rapidez.
context: Lenny asks if there's anything else helpful for people to think about. Amjad gives advice to founders and company leaders about adapting to rapid AI advancement. He explains that traditional business planning approaches like fixed roadmaps are becoming problematic because AI capabilities are advancing so quickly that companies need to be able to pivot immediately when new AI tools or capabilities become available.
vocabulary_highlights: be resilient to that change, react to it really quickly

speaker: Andrew Wilkinson
text: Charlie Munger, Warren Buffett's longtime business partner, has this amazing quote. He says, "Fish where the fish are." And he gives this example, he says, "If you're a fisherman and you see a large pond and all around the pond, there's a whole bunch of fishermen and they're all elbowing each other out of the way. They're all using the best lures, the best fishing line, they all have amazing strategy. You actually want to walk off into the forest and find a small fishing hole with lots of fish and very little competition."
text_ko: 찰리 멍거가 "물고기가 있는 곳에서 낚시해라"라고 했어요. 예를 들어서, 만약 당신이 낚시꾼이고 큰 연못이 있는데 그 주위에 많은 낚시꾼들이 서로 밀치고 있다면, 그들은 모두 최고의 미끼와 낚시줄을 사용하고, 뛰어난 전략을 가지고 있어요. 그럴 때는 오히려 숲으로 가서 경쟁이 적고 물고기가 많은 작은 낚시터를 찾아야 해요.
text_zh: 查理·芒格，沃伦·巴菲特的长期商业伙伴，有一句很精彩的话。他说：“在鱼聚集的地方钓鱼。”他举了一个例子，他说：“如果你是一个渔夫，看到一个大池塘，周围有很多渔夫，他们都在互相挤来挤去，使用最好的鱼饵、最好的钓线，拥有出色的策略。其实你应该走进森林，找到一个小钓点，那里有很多鱼，但竞争很少。”
text_es: Charlie Munger, el socio de negocios de Warren Buffett, tiene esta increíble cita. Él dice: "Pesca donde están los peces". Y pone este ejemplo: "Si eres un pescador y ves un gran estanque rodeado de muchos pescadores que se están empujando unos a otros, todos usando los mejores señuelos, la mejor línea de pesca y con estrategias impresionantes, en realidad deberías alejarte hacia el bosque y encontrar un pequeño lugar de pesca con muchos peces y muy poca competencia".
context: Lenny asks Andrew for his best advice on coming up with a great startup idea. Andrew explains that the biggest mistake entrepreneurs make is choosing businesses that everyone is interested in, like restaurants or cafes, which leads to intense competition and lower margins. He references Charlie Munger's fishing analogy to illustrate why entrepreneurs should seek out profitable niches with less competition rather than fighting in overcrowded markets where margins get squeezed.
vocabulary_highlights: elbowing each other out of the way, best lures, fishing hole, very little competition

speaker: Andrew Wilkinson
text: The biggest mistakes I've made have been going into business models where other people have repeatedly failed and thinking, I can do this better. You can't take a brilliant management team and change a bad business model. Ultimately the business model wins.
text_ko: 내가 저지른 가장 큰 실수는 다른 사람들이 반복적으로 실패한 비즈니스 모델에 뛰어들면서 '내가 이걸 더 잘할 수 있을 거야'라고 생각한 거예요. 훌륭한 경영진이 있어도 나쁜 비즈니스 모델은 바꿀 수 없어요. 결국 비즈니스 모델이 승리하거든요.
text_zh: 我犯过的最大错误就是进入那些别人反复失败的商业模式，心想着我可以做得更好。你无法凭借一个优秀的管理团队来改变一个糟糕的商业模式。最终，商业模式才是决定胜负的关键。
text_es: Los mayores errores que he cometido han sido entrar en modelos de negocio donde otras personas han fracasado repetidamente y pensar que yo puedo hacerlo mejor. No puedes tomar un equipo de gestión brillante y cambiar un mal modelo de negocio. Al final, el modelo de negocio es el que prevalece.
context: Lenny asks Andrew about business ideas that everyone thinks will be great but often fail. Andrew shares from his personal experience of starting a bar and buying a local newspaper, explaining that he made the classic mistake of entering industries with many failed attempts, believing he could succeed where others couldn't. He emphasizes that even exceptional management cannot overcome fundamentally flawed business models - the underlying economics of a business ultimately determine success or failure.
vocabulary_highlights: repeatedly failed, brilliant management team, bad business model
topics: Starting a Company, Strategy & Planning, Decision Making

speaker: Andrew Wilkinson
text: I'm looking for a business though where it is so good that it's hard to mess up, and most businesses are very easy to mess up. One person leaves and the whole business falls apart because it's held together with dental floss and duct tape. And so I'm really looking for what Warren Buffett would call a moat.
text_ko: 저는 정말 잘 돌아가서 망치기 힘든 비즈스를 찾고 있어요. 대부분의 비즈니스는 쉽게 망가질 수 있거든요. 한 사람이 떠나면 전체 비즈니스가 무너지는 경우가 많아요. 마치 치실(dental floss)과 덕트 테이프(duct tape)로 붙여놓은 것처럼요. 그래서 저는 워렌 버핏이 말하는 '모트(moat)'를 찾고 있어요.
text_zh: 我在寻找一种商业模式，它非常稳固，以至于很难出错，而大多数企业都很容易出错。一个人离开，整个业务就会崩溃，因为它是用牙线和胶带维系的。因此，我真正想要的是沃伦·巴菲特所说的护城河（moat）。
text_es: Estoy buscando un negocio que sea tan sólido que sea difícil de arruinar, ya que la mayoría de los negocios son muy fáciles de perjudicar. Una persona se va y todo el negocio se desmorona porque está sostenido con hilo dental y cinta adhesiva. Por eso, realmente estoy buscando lo que Warren Buffett llamaría una "moat" (foso).
context: Lenny asks Andrew about the keys to an amazing business model and what he looks for when buying companies through Tiny. Andrew explains his investment philosophy, which mirrors Warren Buffett's approach of buying businesses that can run themselves. He's seeking companies with strong competitive advantages (moats) that are resilient and don't depend on any single person or fragile systems to operate successfully.
vocabulary_highlights: hard to mess up, held together with dental floss and duct tape, moat

speaker: Andrew Wilkinson
text: It's like having the world's most reliable employee who costs $200 a month and works 24/7. So many knowledge work jobs are going to change massively. I think the fundamental question is, do all jobs just become a single prompt?
text_ko: 마치 세상에서 가장 믿음직한 직원이 한 달에 200달러로 24시간 내내 일하는 것 같아요. 많은 지식 기반 직업들이 엄청나게 변화할 거예요. 제가 생각하기에 근본적인 질문은, 모든 일이 그냥 하나의 프롬프트(prompt)로 바뀌는 걸까요?
text_zh: 这就像拥有世界上最可靠的员工，每月只需200美元，且全天候工作。许多知识工作岗位将发生巨大的变化。我认为根本问题是，所有工作是否都将变成一个简单的提示？
text_es: Es como tener al empleado más confiable del mundo que cuesta $200 al mes y trabaja 24/7. Muchos trabajos de conocimiento (knowledge work) van a cambiar de manera masiva. Creo que la pregunta fundamental es: ¿todos los trabajos se convierten en un solo prompt?
context: Lenny observes that Andrew has become AI obsessed based on his Twitter activity. Andrew describes his experience using AI automation tools, particularly Lindy, to replace tasks that previously required a full-time assistant. He's reflecting on the broader implications of AI for the workforce, questioning whether future jobs might be simplified to just giving AI systems single prompts to execute complex tasks.
vocabulary_highlights: most reliable employee, works 24/7, knowledge work jobs, single prompt

speaker: Andrew Wilkinson
text: I think the fundamental question is do all jobs just become a single prompt? For example, does a CEO just grow the business while making the customers happy and turning a profit or something like that? And it is able to actually be an omniscient presence that can run a whole company.
text_ko: 기본적인 질문은 모든 직업이 결국 하나의 프롬프트로 수렴되는 건가 하는 거예요. 예를 들어, CEO는 고객을 행복하게 하고 이익을 내면서 비즈니스를 성장시키는 역할만 하는 걸까요? 그리고 그런 역할이 실제로 회사를 운영할 수 있는 전지전능한 존재가 될 수 있는 건지 궁금해요.
text_zh: 我认为根本问题在于，所有工作是否最终都变成一个简单的指令？例如，首席执行官（CEO）是否只需在让客户满意和实现盈利的同时发展业务？而且它是否真的能够成为一个全知的存在，能够管理整个公司？
text_es: Creo que la pregunta fundamental es si todos los trabajos se reducen a un solo enunciado. Por ejemplo, ¿un CEO solo se encarga de hacer crecer el negocio, mantener a los clientes satisfechos y generar ganancias, o algo así? Y si realmente puede ser una presencia omnisciente que gestione toda una empresa.
context: Lenny asks Andrew for advice on what new graduates and current workers should focus on given the rapid advancement of AI. Andrew is exploring the philosophical question of how AI might transform work entirely. He's wondering whether future AI systems will be so capable that complex jobs like being a CEO might be reduced to giving a single, high-level instruction, with AI handling all the detailed execution and decision-making.
vocabulary_highlights: single prompt, omniscient presence, run a whole company

speaker: Andrew Wilkinson
text: There's this great William Gibson quote, "The future is already here, it's just not evenly distributed." And I think that we are in the Palm Treo phase. So right now people like me who have the time and skillset to nerd out and build the agents can do this. It's just not accessible to everybody.
text_ko: 윌리엄 깁슨의 명언 중에 "미래는 이미 와 있지만, 고르게 분배되지 않았다"는 말이 있어요. 지금 우리는 팔름 트레오(Palm Treo) 시기에 있는 것 같아요. 그래서 지금 저처럼 시간과 기술이 있는 사람들이 에이전트(agent)를 만들 수 있지만, 이게 모든 사람에게는 접근 가능하지 않은 상황이에요.
text_zh: 威廉·吉布森有句很棒的话：“未来已经到来，只是尚未均匀分布。”我认为我们正处于Palm Treo的阶段。现在，像我这样有时间和技能的人能够去深入研究并构建这些代理（agents），但这并不是每个人都能接触到的。
text_es: "El futuro ya está aquí, solo que no está distribuido de manera equitativa." Creo que estamos en la fase del Palm Treo. En este momento, personas como yo, que tienen el tiempo y las habilidades para profundizar y construir los agentes, pueden hacerlo. Simplemente no es accesible para todos.
context: Lenny asks Andrew about the impact AI will have on job displacement, noting that Andrew no longer needs certain contractors and assistants due to AI automation. Andrew uses a technology adoption analogy, comparing the current state of AI tools to the Palm Treo - a primitive smartphone predecessor that gave early adopters a preview of mobile capabilities but wasn't user-friendly enough for mass adoption. He suggests we're in an early phase where only tech-savvy users can fully leverage AI's potential.
vocabulary_highlights: not evenly distributed, Palm Treo phase, nerd out, not accessible to everybody

speaker: Andy Johns
text: I think one of the things that has been a change for me over the last several years is that I prefer to move forward in my life being completely honest with who I am, not hiding any aspects of myself, including the stuff that in the past I'd be afraid to share.
text_ko: 최근 몇 년 동안 제 삶에서 변화된 점 중 하나는 제 자신을 숨기지 않고 솔직하게 살아가고 싶다는 거예요. 예전에는 공유하기 두려웠던 부분들도 이제는 다 드러내고 싶어요.
text_zh: 在过去的几年里，我认为我最大的变化之一就是我更倾向于在生活中完全诚实地做自己，不再隐藏任何方面，包括过去我曾害怕分享的事情。
text_es: Creo que una de las cosas que ha cambiado para mí en los últimos años es que prefiero avanzar en mi vida siendo completamente honesto con quien soy, sin ocultar ningún aspecto de mí mismo, incluyendo aquellas cosas que en el pasado temía compartir.
context: Lenny mentions that their conversation might get heavy, and Andy responds by explaining his current approach to life and sharing personal information. Andy discusses how he has shifted toward complete honesty and authenticity, no longer concealing parts of himself that he previously would have been reluctant to reveal publicly.
vocabulary_highlights: move forward, aspects of myself, be afraid to share

speaker: Andy Johns
text: So even though I had those successes, there was a lot that I needed to work through that was under the hood, which I eventually came to understand very, very deeply as a result of turning inward and doing a lot of work on my own path towards self-understanding and healing some deep emotional wounds.
text_ko: 그래서 그런 성공이 있었음에도 불구하고, 내면에서 해결해야 할 것들이 많았어요. 결국, 자기 이해와 깊은 감정적 상처를 치유하기 위한 나만의 여정을 통해 그 부분을 정말 깊이 이해하게 되었어요.
text_zh: 尽管我取得了一些成功，但我仍然需要解决许多潜在的问题。通过内省和在自我理解及疗愈深层情感创伤的过程中付出大量努力，我最终对此有了非常深刻的理解。
text_es: A pesar de mis éxitos, había mucho en lo que necesitaba trabajar internamente, lo cual llegué a comprender profundamente gracias a la introspección y al esfuerzo que hice en mi camino hacia la autocomprensión y la sanación de heridas emocionales profundas.
context: Andy explains how despite his professional success in tech companies, he was struggling internally with emotional and psychological issues. He describes the contrast between his outward career achievements and his inner turmoil, explaining how he eventually began a process of deep self-examination to address underlying emotional trauma from his past.
vocabulary_highlights: under the hood, turning inward, emotional wounds

speaker: Andy Johns
text: It got to the point to where there were several occasions while I was at work where I could tell that I was about ready to have a breakdown of sorts, and I would just grab my laptop, throw it in my bag, and pretty quietly just walk out of the office even if it was 10:00 AM and I'd only been there for an hour or two.
text_ko: 일하다 보면 여러 번 힘들어서 무너질 것 같은 순간이 있었어요. 그럴 때면 그냥 노트북을 챙겨서 가방에 넣고, 조용히 사무실을 나가곤 했죠. 오전 10시인데도 불구하고 한두 시간밖에 안 있었던 경우도 많았어요.
text_zh: 在工作中，我曾多次感到快要崩溃，于是我会迅速把笔记本电脑放进包里，悄悄地走出办公室，即使那时才早上10点，我只工作了一个或两个小时。
text_es: Llegó un momento en el que, mientras estaba en el trabajo, me di cuenta de que estaba a punto de tener un colapso, así que simplemente agarraba mi laptop, la metía en mi mochila y salía de la oficina de manera discreta, incluso si eran las 10:00 AM y solo había estado allí una o dos horas.
context: Andy shares specific examples of how his mental health struggles manifested while working at Twitter in 2010. He describes experiencing panic attacks and depression so severe that he would have to suddenly leave work to avoid having a complete breakdown in front of colleagues, illustrating how his professional success was masking serious psychological distress.
vocabulary_highlights: breakdown of sorts, throw it in my bag, pretty quietly

speaker: Andy Johns
text: So I learned very early on that if I wanted to feel good, I needed to achieve, and that if I wanted to love myself and be considered lovable by others, I needed to achieve. That pulled me out of a darkness that I was in for several years as a kid, and I'm glad that it did, and it led to an excellent experience in high school, in college, and then well into my 20s, but eventually, those emotional wounds are going to come to the surface.
text_ko: 저는 어릴 때부터 기분이 좋으려면 성취를 해야 한다는 걸 배웠어요. 그리고 스스로를 사랑하고 다른 사람들에게 사랑받고 싶다면 성취가 필요하다는 것도요. 그 덕분에 몇 년 동안 힘들었던 어둠에서 벗어날 수 있었고, 그게 고등학교, 대학, 그리고 20대 초반까지 좋은 경험으로 이어졌어요. 하지만 결국 그런 감정적인 상처는 언젠가 드러나게 마련이에요.
text_zh: 我很早就意识到，如果我想要感到快乐，就必须有所成就；如果我想要爱自己并被他人视为可爱，就更需要取得成就。这让我摆脱了童年时几年的黑暗，我很庆幸自己能够做到，这也让我在高中、大学以及进入20多岁时都获得了很好的经历，但最终，这些情感创伤终究会浮出水面。
text_es: Desde muy temprano aprendí que si quería sentirme bien, necesitaba lograr cosas, y que si quería amarme a mí mismo y ser considerado digno de amor por los demás, también necesitaba lograr cosas. Eso me sacó de una oscuridad en la que estuve durante varios años de mi infancia, y me alegra que así fuera, ya que me llevó a tener una excelente experiencia en la secundaria, en la universidad y luego en mis 20, pero eventualmente, esas heridas emocionales van a salir a la superficie.
context: Andy explains how childhood trauma from losing his mentally ill mother at age 10 led him to develop an addiction to achievement as a coping mechanism. He describes how society's positive reinforcement for his academic and athletic success became his primary source of self-worth, which worked well initially but eventually became problematic as the underlying emotional issues needed to be addressed.
vocabulary_highlights: pulled me out of, well into my 20s, come to the surface

speaker: Andy Johns
text: So from some of the surveys I've put out from my own anecdotal experience and from some proper research that's been conducted by experts who focus on entrepreneur and high performer wellbeing, I'd say that it's a fair estimate to say that at least 50% to 60% of tech employees who have, just to give it a bit more nuance, who have been in the saddle, so to speak, for a minimum of five to seven years, they're experiencing some form of psychological and emotional distress.
text_ko: 제가 진행한 설문조사와 전문가들이 연구한 결과를 바탕으로 볼 때, 최소 50%에서 60%의 기술 분야 직원들이, 좀 더 구체적으로 말하자면, 최소 5년에서 7년 정도 경력이 있는 분들이 심리적이고 감정적인 스트레스를 겪고 있다고 봐도 무방해요.
text_zh: 根据我自己的一些调查、个人经验以及专家对企业家和高绩效者福祉的研究，我认为可以合理地估计，至少50%到60%的科技行业员工，特别是那些在行业内工作了五到七年的人，正经历某种形式的心理和情感困扰。
text_es: Según algunas encuestas que he realizado, así como investigaciones adecuadas llevadas a cabo por expertos en el bienestar de emprendedores y de alto rendimiento, diría que es una estimación justa afirmar que al menos el 50% al 60% de los empleados en tecnología que, para dar un poco más de contexto, han estado en el sector durante un mínimo de cinco a siete años, están experimentando alguna forma de malestar psicológico y emocional.
context: Lenny asks about the prevalence of mental health struggles in the tech industry. Andy shares data from surveys and research showing that a significant portion of tech workers experience psychological distress. He specifically focuses on employees who have been working in the industry for several years, suggesting that the pressures accumulate over time and affect more than half of experienced tech workers.
vocabulary_highlights: anecdotal experience, proper research, in the saddle, a fair estimate

speaker: Andy Johns
text: These adaptations, if you're unaware of them and if you're unaware of the subconscious drivers that are responsible for them, they run the risk that they go too far, and that these adaptations, which were initially beneficial to you and to your life, they reverse course in a sense, and they become detrimental to your present state and your future development.
text_ko: 이런 적응이 어떤 건지 잘 모르고, 그 뒤에 있는 무의식적인 원인도 모르면, 너무 지나치게 될 위험이 있어요. 처음에는 당신과 당신의 삶에 도움이 됐던 이 적응들이 오히려 현재 상태나 미래 발전에 해가 될 수 있어요.
text_zh: 这些适应，如果你对此毫不知情，也不了解背后的潜在驱动因素，可能会走得太远。这些最初对你和你的生活有益的适应，反而可能会在某种程度上逆转，变得对你当前的状态和未来的发展产生负面影响。
text_es: Estas adaptaciones, si no eres consciente de ellas y de los impulsores subconscientes que las generan, corren el riesgo de ir demasiado lejos, y esas adaptaciones, que inicialmente fueron beneficiosas para ti y para tu vida, pueden revertir su curso, volviéndose perjudiciales para tu estado actual y tu desarrollo futuro.
context: Andy explains how coping mechanisms that help people survive difficult childhood experiences can become harmful later in life. He describes how his achievement-focused mindset, which helped him after his mother's death, eventually became destructive when taken to extremes. The insight is that survival adaptations can outlive their usefulness and become obstacles to wellbeing if people aren't conscious of them.
vocabulary_highlights: subconscious drivers, run the risk, reverse course, detrimental to

speaker: Andy Johns
text: Step two is seeking the truth behind why we suffer. Once the suffering gets so bad in somebody through some spiritual intervention, a legal intervention, the intervention of friends and family, whatever it may be, they decide to change, and in order to change, you have to understand the truth as to who you are and why you are the way you are and why you're suffering.
text_ko: 두 번째 단계는 우리가 왜 고통받는지 그 진실을 찾는 거예요. 누군가의 고통이 너무 심해지면, 영적인 개입이나 법적인 개입, 친구와 가족의 개입 등 어떤 방식으로든 그들은 변화를 결심하게 돼요. 변화를 위해서는 자신이 누구인지, 왜 그런 모습인지, 그리고 왜 고통받고 있는지를 이해해야 해요.
text_zh: 第二步是探寻我们痛苦背后的真相。当一个人的痛苦通过某种精神干预、法律干预或朋友和家人的介入等方式达到极限时，他们会决定改变。要实现改变，就必须理解自己是谁、为什么会这样以及为何会痛苦的真相。
text_es: El segundo paso es buscar la verdad detrás de por qué sufrimos. Una vez que el sufrimiento se vuelve tan intenso en una persona, ya sea a través de una intervención espiritual, una intervención legal, la intervención de amigos y familiares, o cualquier otra cosa, decide cambiar. Y para poder cambiar, es necesario entender la verdad sobre quién eres, por qué eres como eres y por qué estás sufriendo.
context: Andy outlines his four-step framework for deep personal transformation, focusing on the second step after suffering. He explains that meaningful change requires understanding the root causes of one's pain, which involves deep self-examination to uncover subconscious patterns and historical experiences that drive current behavior and emotional states.
vocabulary_highlights: seeking the truth, spiritual intervention, decide to change

speaker: Andy Raskin
text: The way I learned how to pitch in business school, and I think the way most people did is what I call the arrogant doctor. So you have a problem, a pain, I have a solution, a treatment, and I'm going to tell you why it's better than all the other treatments. And the structure that I read about in these movies was different. Every movie starts with some kind of shift in the world, and I call this shift the shift from the old game to a new game.
text_ko: 제가 비즈니스 스쿨에서 피치를 배우면서 느낀 점은, 대부분의 사람들이 배우는 방식이 마치 자만하는 의사 같다는 거예요. 당신에게 문제가 있고, 고통이 있다면, 저는 해결책과 치료법을 가지고 있고, 그게 다른 치료법보다 왜 더 좋은지 설명할 거예요. 그런데 제가 읽었던 영화들에서의 구조는 달랐어요. 모든 영화는 세상에 어떤 변화가 일어나는 것으로 시작하는데, 저는 이 변화를 '구 게임에서 새로운 게임으로의 전환'이라고 부릅니다.
text_zh: 我在商学院学的那套pitch方式，我觉得大多数人学的都是我说的"傲慢医生"那一套。就是你有问题，有痛点，我有解决方案，有治疗方法，然后我要告诉你为什么我的比其他所有方案都好。但我从这些电影里看到的结构不一样。每部电影都是从世界的某种变化开始的，我把这种变化叫做从旧游戏规则到新游戏规则的转变。
text_es: La forma en que aprendí a hacer presentaciones en la escuela de negocios, y creo que la mayoría de la gente también, es lo que yo llamo el doctor arrogante. O sea, tú tienes un problema, un dolor, yo tengo una solución, un tratamiento, y te voy a decir por qué es mejor que todos los otros tratamientos. Pero la estructura que leí en estas películas era diferente. Cada película empieza con algún tipo de cambio en el mundo, y a este cambio yo lo llamo el cambio del juego viejo al juego nuevo.
context: Andy introduces his background and explains how he discovered a different approach to pitching. He contrasts the traditional business school method (which he calls the 'arrogant doctor' approach) with the storytelling structure he learned from screenwriting books. The 'arrogant doctor' method focuses on presenting problems and solutions, while his preferred approach starts by establishing a fundamental shift happening in the world - from an old way of doing things to a new way.
vocabulary_highlights: arrogant doctor, shift from the old game to a new game

speaker: Andy Raskin
text: This structure really is about defining a movement, and that's very different from, 'Hey, I'm going to solve your problem.' What I think is really interesting as a kind of qualifier is that this story has a certain structure. And the traditional structure, the way I learned how to pitch in business school, I think the way most people did is what I call the arrogant doctor.
text_ko: 이 구조는 사실 어떤 운동(movement)을 정의하는 것에 관한 거예요. 그리고 그건 '내가 네 문제를 해결해 줄게'라는 식의 접근과는 완전히 달라요. 흥미로운 건 이 이야기에 일정한 구조가 있다는 점이에요. 제가 비즈니스 스쿨에서 피칭(pitch)을 배우면서 익힌 전통적인 방식, 즉 대부분 사람들이 해오던 방식은 제가 '거만한 의사(arrogant doctor)'라고 부르는 방식이에요.
text_zh: 这个框架其实就是在定义一个运动，这和"嘿，我来帮你解决问题"是完全不同的概念。我觉得特别有意思的一点是，这个故事有它特定的结构。而传统的那套结构，也就是我在商学院学的那种推销方式，我想大多数人学的都是这样，我把它叫做"傲慢医生"模式。
text_es: Esta estructura realmente se trata de definir un movimiento, y eso es muy diferente a decir "Oye, te voy a resolver tu problema." Lo que me parece realmente interesante como una especie de criterio es que esta historia tiene una estructura específica. Y la estructura tradicional, la forma en que aprendí a hacer presentaciones en la escuela de negocios, creo que la forma en que la mayoría de la gente lo hizo, es lo que yo llamo el doctor arrogante.
context: Lenny asks Andy to define what a strategic narrative is. Andy explains that it's one story that CEOs use to drive success across marketing, sales, product, fundraising, and recruiting. He emphasizes that this approach is about defining a movement rather than simply solving problems. Andy contrasts his recommended structure with the traditional 'arrogant doctor' approach where you present a problem and then explain why your solution is better than competitors.
vocabulary_highlights: defining a movement, as a kind of qualifier

speaker: Andy Raskin
text: What's really, I think key is naming it, naming that old game. The examples you saw, software, cloud, transactions, subscription opinions, reality. This very, very concise naming is really key. And it's hard because in making it compact you're losing completeness. So you can imagine you're in a meeting, someone says like, 'Hey, how about we do transactions to subscriptions?' And someone says, 'Well I don't know, there's a lot of things I don't really subscribe to. Subscription economy, really?' So we're always kind of overstating it in a way, but it's not a problem.
text_ko: 제가 보기엔 핵심은 그걸 이름 붙이는 거예요 — 그 오래된 방식을 이름으로 규정하는 것. 방금 보신 예들, 소프트웨어(software), 클라우드(cloud), 트랜잭션(transactions), 구독(subscription) 같은 아주 간결한 네이밍이 정말 중요해요. 근데 간결하게 하다 보면 완전성을 잃게 되니까 어려워요. 회의에서 누군가 ‘트랜잭션에서 구독으로 해볼까요?(transactions to subscriptions)’라고 하면, 다른 사람이 ‘글쎄요, 제가 꼭 구독하고 싶은 게 다 있는 건 아니에요. 구독 경제(subscription economy)라니, 정말?’이라고 말할 수 있잖아요. 그래서 우리는 어쩔 수 없이 어느 정도 과장해서 표현하긴 하는데, 그게 문제되진 않아요.
text_zh: 我觉得最关键的其实就是给它起个名字，把那套老玩法给定义出来。你们刚才看到的那些例子，软件啊、云啊、交易啊、订阅模式啊什么的。这种特别简洁的命名真的很关键。但难就难在，你要做得简洁，就肯定会丢掉一些完整性。你可以想象一下，开会的时候有人说："嘿，咱们要不试试从交易模式转到订阅模式？"然后就有人说："我不太确定啊，有很多东西我其实不太认同订阅这个说法。订阅经济(subscription economy)，真的吗？"所以我们其实总是在某种程度上夸大其词，但这不是问题。
text_es: Lo que creo que es clave de verdad es ponerle nombre, nombrar ese juego anterior. Los ejemplos que vieron - software, nube (cloud), transacciones, suscripciones, opiniones, realidad. Esa forma tan, tan concisa de nombrarlo es realmente clave. Y es difícil porque al hacerlo compacto pierdes completitud. Entonces te puedes imaginar que estás en una junta, alguien dice "Oye, ¿qué tal si pasamos de transacciones a suscripciones?" Y alguien más dice "Pues no sé, hay muchas cosas a las que realmente no me suscribiría. ¿Economía de suscripciones, en serio?" Entonces siempre estamos como exagerando un poco, pero no es problema.
context: Lenny asks Andy to explain the framework for strategic narratives in more detail. Andy explains that one crucial element is naming both the old game and new game very concisely - like 'software to cloud' or 'transactions to subscriptions.' He acknowledges that this compact naming requires some oversimplification and that people might challenge whether the shift is really as universal as claimed, but argues this isn't actually a problem in practice.
vocabulary_highlights: concise naming, overstating it in a way

speaker: Andy Raskin
text: And whenever I work with teams and I talk about this, so they're like, 'Okay, I guess we got to then for kill the prospect's aunt and uncle,' and basically yes, I mean figuratively. We got to show them that the future is not going to just be sort of okay. They see it as split between a very negative outcome and a potentially very positive outcome.
text_ko: 제가 팀들과 이 얘기를 하면 사람들이 농담 반으로 "그럼 잠재 고객(prospect)의 이모·삼촌을 죽여야 한다는 거예요?"라고 해요. 말하자면 비유적인 표현이에요. 우리가 보여줘야 할 건 미래가 그냥 그럭저럭 괜찮을 거라는 식이 아니라는 거예요. 그들은 미래를 아주 부정적인 결과와 잠재적으로 매우 긍정적인 결과로 나눠서 보고 있어요.
text_zh: 每次我跟团队讲这个的时候，他们就会说，'好吧，那我们得把潜在客户的七大姑八大姨都给'搞定'了'，基本上就是这个意思，当然是比喻啦。我们得让他们明白，未来不会就这么平平淡淡的。要让他们看到两个极端：要么结果很糟糕，要么有可能非常好。
text_es: Y siempre que trabajo con equipos y hablo de esto, me dicen: "Bueno, entonces supongo que tenemos que matar a los tíos del prospecto," y básicamente sí, pero en sentido figurado. Tenemos que demostrarles que el futuro no va a ser simplemente más o menos bien. Tienen que verlo dividido entre un resultado muy negativo y otro potencialmente muy positivo.
context: Andy uses a Star Wars analogy to explain how to create urgency in strategic narratives. He references how Luke Skywalker initially refuses the call to adventure until his aunt and uncle are killed, making the stakes life-and-death. Andy explains that in business pitches, you need to show prospects that their future won't be 'sort of okay' - there will be clear winners and losers based on whether they adapt to the new paradigm or stick with the old way.
vocabulary_highlights: kill the prospect's aunt and uncle, sort of okay

speaker: Andy Raskin
text: Another thing I just hear always, I just interviewed a CEO this morning for my podcast and this is the first thing he actually said was, 'It becomes the strategic north star for the product.' So what he was telling me, and this was actually a little unusual, I asked him, 'Why did you come to me at first?' And of course I'd asked him that before, but he said something this time that was a little different from what I'd heard before. He said, 'We are constantly getting feature requests through sales, through customer success. And we had sort of no way, bar to decide well what do we take on, what don't we take on? And this clearly has become our bar.'
text_ko: 또 늘 듣는 얘기가 하나 있어요. 오늘 아침 팟캐스트에서 CEO를 인터뷰했는데, 그가 제일 먼저 한 말이 "이게 제품의 전략적 북극성(strategic north star)이 된다"였어요. 그가 제게 하려던 얘기는 이러했는데, 좀 특이한 점도 있었어요. 제가 "처음에 왜 저한테 오셨나요?"라고 물었더니, 전에 물어본 적도 있지만 이번엔 전과는 조금 다른 답을 주더라고요. 그는 "우리는 영업(sales)과 고객 성공(customer success)을 통해 계속 기능 요청(feature requests)을 받고 있어요. 그런데 무엇을 수용하고 무엇을 안 할지 판단할 기준(bar)이 사실상 없었어요. 그런데 이게 분명 우리의 기준이 됐어요."라고 말했어요.
text_zh: 还有一件事我经常听到，今天早上我在播客里采访了一个CEO，他第一句话就是："这成了我们产品的战略北极星(strategic north star)。" 他跟我说的是，其实挺特别的，我问他："你当初为什么来找我？" 当然我之前也问过他这个问题，但这次他说的跟以前有点不一样。他说："我们总是从销售那边、从客服成功(customer success)那边收到各种功能需求，我们根本没办法决定哪些该做，哪些不该做。现在这个就成了我们的标准。"
text_es: Otra cosa que escucho siempre, justo esta mañana entrevisté a un CEO para mi podcast y esto fue lo primero que me dijo: "Se convierte en la estrella polar estratégica del producto (strategic north star)". Entonces lo que me estaba diciendo, y esto sí fue un poco raro, le pregunté: "¿Por qué viniste conmigo en primer lugar?" Y claro, ya le había preguntado eso antes, pero esta vez me dijo algo un poquito diferente a lo que había escuchado antes. Me dijo: "Constantemente nos llegan solicitudes de funcionalidades a través de ventas, a través de customer success. Y no teníamos como una forma, un criterio para decidir qué tomamos y qué no tomamos. Y esto claramente se ha convertido en nuestro criterio."
context: Lenny asks about the impact Andy has seen from companies shifting to his strategic narrative approach. Andy explains that beyond helping with sales and marketing, the strategic narrative becomes a decision-making framework for product development. A CEO Andy recently interviewed explained that they were constantly receiving feature requests from sales and customer success teams but had no clear criteria for prioritization until they developed their strategic narrative, which now serves as their filter for what features to build.
vocabulary_highlights: strategic north star, no way, bar to decide
topics: Product Management, Strategy & Planning, Decision Making

speaker: Andy Raskin
text: But I guess I feel like still by calling it category and category name, we're just focusing on those three words so much. And what happens often is CEOs will, they'll kind of come up with this little category, like what happened with Nick at the 360Learning with collaborative learning. We have this name, but we don't know how to tell the story around it. So my feeling is like, well, let's focus on the story.
text_ko: 근데 저는 여전히 '카테고리(category)'나 '카테고리 이름'이라는 말에만 너무 집착하는 것 같아요. 그리고 자주 있는 일은 CEO들이 작은 카테고리를 만들어놓고—360Learning의 Nick 사례처럼 '협업 학습(collaborative learning)'이라는 이름은 있는데—그걸 둘러싼 이야기를 어떻게 풀어야 할지 모르는 거예요. 그래서 제 생각에는 이야기에 집중하자는 거예요.
text_zh: 但我觉得吧，我们老是纠结在"品类"和"品类名称"这几个词上，太钻牛角尖了。经常发生的情况就是，CEO们会想出一个小品类概念，就像Nick在360Learning搞的那个协作学习(collaborative learning)一样。名字是有了，但不知道怎么讲好这个故事。所以我的想法是，咱们还是把重点放在讲故事上吧。
text_es: Pero creo que al seguir llamándolo categoría y nombre de categoría, nos estamos enfocando demasiado en esas tres palabras. Y lo que pasa seguido es que los CEOs van a inventarse esta pequeña categoría, como lo que pasó con Nick en 360Learning con el aprendizaje colaborativo. Tenemos este nombre, pero no sabemos cómo contar la historia alrededor de él. Entonces mi sensación es que, bueno, enfoquémonos en la historia.
context: Lenny asks Andy about his perspective on category creation, noting that Andy doesn't seem to be a big fan of this popular approach. Andy explains that while he's not entirely against category creation, he believes people get too focused on finding the perfect category name (usually three words) rather than developing the underlying story. He argues that CEOs often create category names but then struggle to build a compelling narrative around them, which is why he prefers to focus on story and movement creation first.
vocabulary_highlights: come up with this little category

speaker: Andy Raskin
text: Well, I can tell you what I hear from CEOs when they contact me. I always ask, what's happening? Because that idea I had, no CEO's going to budget a line item for this. I'm basically asking, why was I wrong? So a few things they tell me, one is that the company is maturing from a point a stage where they've been successful, but that success is ... one CEO put it this way, was brute force of the founders.
text_ko: 글쎄요, CEO들이 연락할 때 제가 듣는 얘기를 말씀드릴게요. 저는 항상 "무슨 일이죠?"라고 물어요. 제 생각엔 그 아이디어에 대해 어떤 CEO도 이걸 위해 예산 항목(line item)을 잡지 않을 거라고 생각하니까요. 사실 제가 묻는 건, "제가 왜 틀렸지?"예요. 그들이 제게 하는 얘기 중 몇 가지가 있는데, 하나는 회사가 성공을 거둔 단계에서 한 단계 더 성숙해지고 있다는 거예요. 그런데 그 성공은… 한 CEO가 그러더군요, 창업자들이 힘으로 밀어붙여 얻은 성공(brute force)이라고요.
text_zh: 我可以跟你说说那些CEO联系我的时候都跟我反映什么。我总是会问，到底出了什么事？因为我那个想法，没有哪个CEO会专门为这个事儿单独做预算的。我基本上就是在问，我哪里想错了？他们跟我说的情况主要有这么几个，其中一个就是公司正在从一个阶段走向成熟，之前他们是成功的，但是这种成功...有个CEO是这么说的，完全就是靠创始人的蛮干。
text_es: Bueno, te puedo contar lo que escucho de los CEOs cuando me contactan. Siempre les pregunto, ¿qué está pasando? Porque con esa idea que tenía, ningún CEO va a meter una partida presupuestaria para esto. Básicamente estoy preguntando, ¿en qué me equivoqué? Entonces me dicen varias cosas, una es que la empresa está madurando desde un punto, una etapa donde han tenido éxito, pero ese éxito es... un CEO lo puso así, fue por la fuerza bruta de los fundadores.
context: Lenny asks what signs indicate that a company should work on their strategic narrative. Andy explains that he originally thought no CEO would budget for narrative work, so he always asks CEOs why they're reaching out. One common scenario is when companies are maturing beyond the stage where success depended on the founders being directly involved in every decision - what one CEO called 'brute force of the founders' - and they need a way to scale their vision and decision-making across the growing organization.
vocabulary_highlights: budget a line item for this, brute force of the founders

speaker: Anneka Gupta
speaker_expertise: Product Management, Growth Strategy, Leadership Development
text: When people say, "I want someone that's strategic," what they're really saying is, "I want someone that can come up with and articulate a compelling and simple why behind the decisions and the direction of the company and product." So that's number one. And the second piece is, "I want someone that's going to champion and be a change agent to do things that may be hard but actually best for the long-term interest of the product or company, even though those things are not going to be easy to execute on."
text_ko: 사람들이 “전략적인 사람을 원해요”라고 말할 때, 사실 그들이 진짜로 원하는 건 “회사와 제품의 방향·의사결정 뒤에 있는 설득력 있고 단순한 이유(why)를 찾아내고 그걸 명확히 설명할 수 있는 사람”이에요. 그게 첫 번째예요. 두 번째는 “실행하기 쉽지 않을지라도 제품이나 회사의 장기적 이익에 진짜로 도움이 되는 일들을 옹호하고 추진하며 변화를 이끄는 사람(champion, change agent)을 원한다”는 거예요.
text_zh: 当别人说"我想要一个有战略眼光的人"的时候，他们真正想表达的是："我想要一个能够想出并清楚说明公司和产品决策背后那个有说服力且简单明了的原因的人。"这是第一点。第二点是："我想要一个能够推动变革、做变革推手(change agent)的人，去做那些可能很难但对产品或公司长远利益真正有好处的事情，哪怕这些事情执行起来不会那么容易。"
text_es: Cuando la gente dice "quiero a alguien estratégico", lo que realmente están diciendo es "quiero a alguien que pueda crear y explicar de manera clara y convincente el por qué detrás de las decisiones y la dirección de la empresa y el producto". Esa es la primera parte. Y la segunda es "quiero a alguien que vaya a liderar y ser un agente de cambio para hacer cosas que tal vez sean difíciles pero que realmente convengan a largo plazo para el producto o la empresa, aunque no vayan a ser fáciles de ejecutar".
context: Lenny asks Anneka what it means to be strategic after she mentions receiving feedback earlier in her career that she wasn't strategic enough. Anneka breaks down what being strategic actually means in business contexts. She explains that strategic thinking requires two key components: first, the ability to create and clearly communicate the reasoning behind business decisions, and second, being willing to push for difficult but necessary changes that benefit the company long-term.
vocabulary_highlights: compelling and simple why, champion and be a change agent, long-term interest

speaker: Anneka Gupta
speaker_expertise: Product Management, Growth Strategy, Leadership Development
text: My one mindset that I really have leaned into after someone actually gave me advice on this is to figure out how to have fun in my job, even in the most difficult of times.
