The reason why I say that is because when you're hit with really hard times, it's easy to operate from a mindset of scarcity and to look at everything as an unachievable hurdle to overcome.
text_ko: 누군가 조언해줘서 제가 정말 마음에 새긴 한 가지 사고방식은, 가장 어려운 시기에도 어떻게 하면 일에서 즐거움을 찾을지 고민하는 거예요. 그 이유는 정말 힘든 시기를 맞으면 결핍 마인드셋(scarcity mindset)에 빠지기 쉬워서, 모든 걸 못 넘을 장벽처럼 보이거든요.
text_zh: 有人给过我一个建议，我现在特别认同，就是无论多困难的时候，都要想办法在工作中找到乐趣。我为什么这么说呢？因为当你遇到特别大的困难时，很容易就会有那种稀缺心态(scarcity mindset)，觉得什么事都是跨不过去的坎儿。
text_es: Una mentalidad que realmente he adoptado después de que alguien me diera este consejo es descubrir cómo disfrutar mi trabajo, incluso en los momentos más difíciles. La razón por la que digo esto es porque cuando te enfrentas a tiempos muy duros, es fácil funcionar desde una mentalidad de escasez y ver todo como un obstáculo imposible de superar.
context: Lenny asks Anneka about the key skills or mindsets that contributed most to her successful career. Anneka shares her approach to reframing difficult workplace situations. She explains how someone advised her to find ways to enjoy challenging work situations rather than viewing them negatively. This mental shift helps her avoid a scarcity mindset where problems seem insurmountable and instead opens her mind to creative solutions and opportunities.
vocabulary_highlights: leaned into, mindset of scarcity, unachievable hurdle to overcome
topics: Career Development, Leadership & Management, Work-Life Balance

speaker: Anneka Gupta
speaker_expertise: Product Management, Growth Strategy, Leadership Development
text: I always think about I have all the people around me. Whether they're people on my team, my peers, or my CEO, these are different resources I have to go get a initiative done or get work done in the company. And as having a founder that can effectively operate in founder mode means that I can go and have a conversation with the CEO and say, "Hey, look, we have this huge opportunity and these are the things that aren't working, and I need your help to help figure out how we can move the needle more substantially in the direction that we need to go."
text_ko: 저는 항상 제 주변에 사람이 있다는 걸 생각해요. 팀원, 동료, 심지어 CEO까지—이 사람들 모두 회사에서 어떤 일을 추진하거나 이니셔티브(initiative)를 성사시키는 데 제가 활용할 수 있는 다양한 자원이에요. 그리고 창업자 모드(founder mode)로 효율적으로 활동할 수 있다는 건 CEO와 직접 만나 이렇게 말할 수 있다는 뜻이에요. "저희한테 큰 기회가 있는데 지금 잘 안 되고 있는 부분들이 있어요. 우리가 가야 할 방향으로 성과를 눈에 띄게 개선하려면 도움을 주셔야 해요. 어떻게 하면 더 크게 변화를 만들 수 있을지 함께 방법을 찾아주시면 좋겠어요."
text_zh: 我一直觉得，我身边的这些人都是我的资源。不管是我团队里的人，还是同事，或者是CEO，这些都是我推进项目、完成工作时可以调动的不同资源。作为一个能够有效运用创始人模式(founder mode)的创始人，我可以直接去找CEO聊，跟他说："嘿，你看，我们现在有个巨大的机会，但这些地方卡住了，我需要你帮忙想想办法，怎么能让我们在这个方向上有更大的突破。"
text_es: Siempre pienso en toda la gente que tengo alrededor. Ya sean personas de mi equipo, mis colegas, o mi CEO, estos son diferentes recursos que tengo para sacar adelante una iniciativa o hacer que las cosas funcionen en la empresa. Y como fundador que puede operar efectivamente en modo fundador (founder mode), significa que puedo ir y tener una conversación con el CEO y decirle, "Oye, mira, tenemos esta oportunidad enorme y estas son las cosas que no están funcionando, y necesito tu ayuda para que me ayudes a descifrar cómo podemos mover la aguja (move the needle) de manera más contundente en la dirección que necesitamos ir."
context: Lenny asks Anneka how to effectively work as a product leader with a founder operating in founder mode, referring to Paul Graham's recent concept. Anneka explains her strategic approach to leveraging founder mode positively. Rather than seeing a founder's direct involvement as interference, she views the founder as a powerful resource who can drive change that others in the organization cannot. She describes how to activate this resource by identifying opportunities and asking for the founder's help in making substantial progress.
vocabulary_highlights: move the needle more substantially

speaker: Anneka Gupta
speaker_expertise: Product Management, Growth Strategy, Leadership Development
text: What I've found is that understanding the details of the business and asking questions and understanding to the utmost extent you can, what's working, what's not, what are the financial goals of the business? Are we on track to get there? How are we making decisions? Getting into that level of depth is super important, and then you can decide as a leader, what do you want to do with that information.
text_ko: 제가 발견한 건, 비즈니스의 세부를 이해하고 질문을 던지며 최대한 파악하는 거예요. 뭐가 잘 되고 있고 뭐가 안 되는지, 사업의 재무 목표(financial goals)가 무엇인지, 그 목표에 도달하고 있는지, 의사결정은 어떻게 이뤄지는지 같은 것들이요. 그런 수준까지 깊이 들어가는 게 정말 중요하고, 그다음 리더로서 그 정보를 가지고 무엇을 할지 결정하면 돼요.
text_zh: 我发现，深入了解业务细节，多问问题，尽可能地搞清楚哪些地方运转得好，哪些地方有问题，公司的财务目标是什么？我们能按计划实现吗？我们是怎么做决策的？深挖到这个程度特别关键，然后你作为领导就能决定拿这些信息怎么办了。
text_es: Lo que he descubierto es que entender los detalles del negocio a fondo y hacer preguntas, comprender al máximo lo que funciona y lo que no, cuáles son las metas financieras de la empresa... ¿Vamos por buen camino para lograrlas? ¿Cómo estamos tomando las decisiones? Meterte en ese nivel de profundidad es súper importante, y entonces ya puedes decidir como líder qué quieres hacer con esa información.
context: Lenny asks Anneka about operating in founder mode as a product leader, since she's been described as someone who excels in this approach. Anneka explains her philosophy of deep business understanding as the foundation of effective leadership. She emphasizes that leaders should gather detailed information about business performance, financial metrics, and decision-making processes, even if they don't act on all of it immediately. This comprehensive knowledge allows leaders to make informed decisions about when and where to intervene.
vocabulary_highlights: to the utmost extent, getting into that level of depth

speaker: Anneka Gupta
speaker_expertise: Product Management, Growth Strategy, Leadership Development
text: The first step that I found as very useful, and I use this tactic every single day in meetings, is just summarization. So, bringing people together, lots of different voices into a room and hearing what they have to say and at various times in the conversation summarizing what people are saying and summarizing what that means in terms of the direction that we could go in.
text_ko: 제가 아주 유용하다고 느껴서 회의에서 매일 쓰는 방법은 바로 요약(summarization)이에요. 여러 사람, 다양한 목소리를 한자리에 모아 각자의 얘기를 듣고 대화 중간중간 그 내용을 요약하면서 우리가 나아갈 방향이 무엇인지 정리해주는 거예요.
text_zh: 我发现第一个特别管用的方法，我现在每天开会都在用，就是总结。把大家聚到一起，听各种不同的声音和想法，然后在谈话过程中不时地总结一下大家说了什么，还有总结一下这些意见对我们未来方向的意义。
text_es: Lo primero que me ha resultado súper útil, y es algo que uso todos los días en las reuniones, es simplemente hacer resúmenes. O sea, juntar a la gente, traer diferentes voces a la sala, escuchar lo que tienen que decir, y en varios momentos de la conversación ir resumiendo lo que están diciendo y qué significa eso en cuanto a la dirección que podríamos tomar.
context: Lenny asks Anneka for a concrete example of how she demonstrates strategic thinking in her work. Anneka shares a practical tactic she uses daily to appear more strategic and drive better outcomes. She explains how effective summarization in meetings - gathering diverse perspectives and then synthesizing them into clear direction - is actually viewed as strategic thinking by others. This approach helps create alignment and moves conversations forward productively while positioning the summarizer as a strategic thinker.
vocabulary_highlights: lots of different voices, at various times in the conversation
topics: Leadership & Management, Communication Skills, Strategy & Planning

speaker: Anneka Gupta
speaker_expertise: Product Management, Growth Strategy, Leadership Development
text: Very easy to get into analysis paralysis before making a decision and say, "Well, if I just had this one more data point, if I just knew this, then I could make a decision." But the reality is that you were always operating off of imprecise information as a product leader. What I've found is that once you commit to a decision, you actually learn more post committing to that decision about what's going to work and not going to work, and you move out of the hypothetical.
text_ko: 결정을 내리기 전에 분석 마비(analysis paralysis)에 빠지기 정말 쉬워요. ‘데이터 하나만 더 있으면, 이거 하나만 알면 결정을 내릴 수 있을 텐데’ 하고들 말하죠. 하지만 현실은 제품 리더(product leader)로서 항상 불완전한 정보로 움직여 왔다는 거예요. 제 경험상 한 번 결정을 내리고 실행해 보면 오히려 그 결정을 하고 나서야 무엇이 통하고 무엇이 통하지 않는지 더 많이 알게 되고, 가정 속에서 벗어나게 돼요.
text_zh: 做决策前特别容易陷入分析瘫痪(analysis paralysis)，总想着"要是我再多个数据点就好了，要是我知道这个信息，我就能做决定了。"但现实是，作为产品负责人，你拿到的信息本来就不可能完全准确。我发现一旦你下定决心做了决策，反而能学到更多东西——什么行得通，什么行不通，而且不再是纸上谈兵了。
text_es: Es facilísimo caer en la parálisis del análisis antes de tomar una decisión y decir, "Bueno, si tan solo tuviera este dato más, si supiera esto, entonces sí podría decidir." Pero la realidad es que como líder de producto siempre estás operando con información imprecisa. Lo que he descubierto es que una vez que te comprometes con una decisión, en realidad aprendes más después de haberte comprometido con esa decisión sobre qué va a funcionar y qué no, y sales de lo hipotético.
context: Lenny shares advice that Anneka once gave to a former colleague about decision-making: "it's not about making the right decision, it's about making the decision." He asks her to explain this philosophy. Anneka discusses the common trap of analysis paralysis that product leaders face when trying to gather perfect information before deciding. She argues that making decisions with imperfect information (around 70% confidence) actually generates more learning than endless analysis, because execution reveals insights that speculation cannot provide.
vocabulary_highlights: analysis paralysis, imprecise information, move out of the hypothetical

speaker: Anneka Gupta
speaker_expertise: Product Management, Growth Strategy, Leadership Development
text: I try to embody the mindset of feeling like and believing that I can work with anyone. I think what I do when I hit a difficult personality and difficult personalities come in all shapes and sizes and forms is I really try to understand what drives that person. What is it that they really care about? Hopefully they care about something deeply about the company and making the company successful. Sometimes they care about their own personal career, how they're showing up, what people view of them.
text_ko: 저는 누구와도 함께 일할 수 있다고 느끼고 믿는 마인드셋(mindset)을 실제로 실천하려고 해요. 성격이 까다로운 사람을 만날 때—사람 성격은 정말 천차만별이죠—제가 하는 일은 그 사람이 무엇에 의해 움직이는지, 무엇을 진짜로 중요하게 여기는지를 깊이 이해하려고 노력하는 거예요. 그 사람이 진짜로 신경 쓰는 게 뭔지 파악하려는 거죠. 다행히도 어떤 사람들은 회사와 회사의 성공에 대해 깊이 신경 쓰는 경우가 있고, 하지만 때로는 자신의 커리어나 자신이 어떻게 보이는지, 다른 사람들이 자신을 어떻게 보는지에 더 신경 쓰기도 해요.
text_zh: 我努力保持一种心态，就是觉得自己能跟任何人合作。当我遇到那些比较难相处的人时——这种人什么样的都有——我会尽量去理解这个人的驱动力是什么。他们真正在乎的是什么？最好的情况是他们对公司很上心，希望公司能成功。有时候他们更关心自己的职业发展，在乎自己在别人眼里的表现和形象。
text_es: Trato de tener la mentalidad de sentir que puedo trabajar con cualquier persona. Creo que cuando me topo con una personalidad difícil - y las personalidades difíciles vienen de todos los colores y sabores - lo que hago es realmente tratar de entender qué es lo que motiva a esa persona. ¿Qué es lo que realmente le importa? Ojalá que les importe algo profundamente sobre la empresa y hacer que la empresa sea exitosa. A veces les importa su propia carrera, cómo se están proyectando, qué imagen tienen ante los demás.
context: Lenny asks Anneka about her ability to navigate very difficult personalities in the workplace, based on feedback from a former colleague who praised this skill. Anneka explains her approach to working with challenging people. Rather than avoiding or fighting difficult personalities, she focuses on understanding their core motivations - whether that's company success, personal career advancement, or reputation. By identifying what drives someone, she can find ways to align their interests with her own objectives.
vocabulary_highlights: embody the mindset, come in all shapes and sizes and forms

speaker: Annie Duke
text: It's so incredibly necessary in improving decision quality to take what's implicit and make it explicit. It's not that intuition is crap, your intuition is sometimes right. If you don't make it explicit, then you don't get to find out when it's wrong.
text_ko: 의사결정의 질(decision quality)을 높이려면 암묵적인 것(implicit)을 명시적인 것(explicit)으로 드러내는 게 정말 중요해요. 그렇다고 직관(intuition)이 쓸모없다는 건 아니에요 — 직관이 맞을 때도 있어요. 다만 그걸 명시화하지 않으면 언제 틀렸는지 알 수 있는 기회를 얻지 못해요.
text_zh: 想要提升决策质量，最关键的就是把那些模模糊糊的想法说清楚、讲明白。不是说直觉不靠谱，有时候你的直觉确实是对的。但如果你不把它摊开来说，那你永远不知道什么时候它是错的。
text_es: Es súper importante para mejorar la calidad de nuestras decisiones sacar a la luz lo que tenemos implícito y hacerlo explícito. No es que la intuición sea una porquería, a veces tu intuición está en lo correcto. Pero si no la haces explícita, entonces nunca te vas a enterar de cuándo está equivocada.
context: Lenny asks Annie about decision-making frameworks and what simple changes have the most impact on companies' decision-making abilities. Annie explains her core philosophy about making implicit knowledge explicit. She clarifies that intuition isn't inherently bad - it can be right sometimes - but the problem is that if we don't explicitly examine our intuitive judgments, we never learn when they're wrong, which prevents us from improving our decision quality.
vocabulary_highlights: make it explicit, intuition is crap

speaker: Annie Duke
text: People generally think the purpose of a meeting is for three things, discover, discuss, decide. The only thing that's ever supposed to happen in a meeting is the discussion part.
text_ko: 사람들은 보통 회의 목적을 발견(discover), 논의(discuss), 결정(decide) 이렇게 세 가지로 보지만, 사실 회의에서 실제로 일어나야 하는 건 논의(discuss)뿐이에요.
text_zh: 大家一般都觉得开会有三个目的：发现问题、讨论问题、做决定。但其实呢，会议上真正应该做的事情就只有讨论这一件事。
text_es: La gente generalmente piensa que las reuniones sirven para tres cosas: descubrir, discutir y decidir. Pero en realidad, lo único que debería pasar en una reunión es la parte de discusión.
context: Lenny asks Annie about the tactics and frameworks that stick when companies try to make better decisions. Annie introduces her framework for restructuring meetings to improve decision quality. She explains that most people believe meetings should serve three functions: discovering people's opinions, discussing those opinions, and making decisions. However, her key insight is that only the discussion portion should happen in meetings - the discovery and decision-making should occur separately.

speaker: Annie Duke
text: So a pre-mortem, it's great only if you set up kill criteria. Commit to actions that you're going to take if you see those signals.
text_ko: 프리모템(pre-mortem)은 킬 기준(kill criteria)을 미리 정해둬야 효과 있어요. 그런 신호가 보이면 어떤 조치를 취할지 분명히 약속하고 바로 실행해요.
text_zh: 所以事前验尸(pre-mortem)这个方法，只有设定了明确的叫停标准(kill criteria)才真正有用。关键是要提前承诺——一旦看到那些危险信号，就必须采取行动。
text_es: Entonces, un pre-mortem solo funciona bien si defines criterios de cancelación. Tienes que comprometerte con las acciones que vas a tomar si ves esas señales.
context: Lenny brings up pre-mortems, a framework commonly used in product development where teams think ahead of time about what might go wrong with their plans. Annie explains that pre-mortems are only effective if they're paired with specific kill criteria - predetermined signals that indicate when it's time to pivot or stop a project. The key is not just identifying potential problems, but committing to specific actions you'll take if those warning signals appear.
vocabulary_highlights: kill criteria
topics: Product Management, Decision Making, Strategy & Planning

speaker: Annie Duke
text: There is no such thing as a long feedback loop. And the way you choose to shorten the feedback loop is to say, what are the things that are correlated with the outcome that I eventually desire?
text_ko: 긴 피드백 루프(feedback loop)라는 건 없어요. 피드백 루프를 단축하는 방법은 결국 내가 궁극적으로 원하는 결과(outcome)와 연관된 것들이 무엇인지 파악하는 거예요.
text_zh: 根本就没有什么反馈循环(feedback loop)应该很长的道理。你要想缩短这个反馈循环(feedback loop)，就得问自己：哪些东西跟我最终想要的结果是有关联的？
text_es: No existe algo así como un ciclo de retroalimentación (feedback loop) largo. Y la forma en que eliges acortar ese ciclo de retroalimentación es preguntándote: ¿cuáles son las cosas que están correlacionadas con el resultado que finalmente quiero lograr?
context: Lenny asks Annie about her framework for evaluating decision quality when outcomes take a very long time to materialize, such as in investing where results may not be known for years. Annie challenges the concept of long feedback loops entirely. She argues that you can always choose to shorten feedback loops by identifying leading indicators - things that are necessary for success or correlated with your ultimate desired outcome - and tracking those much earlier.
vocabulary_highlights: feedback loop

speaker: Annie Duke
text: He was so humble, he really wanted to hear what you thought. He said, 'I don't know a lot', he would change his mind. It's funny, I got asked in a class that I was teaching about thinking fast and slow and someone was talking about how there's a lot of studies in there that didn't end up replicating.
text_ko: 그 사람은 정말 겸손했어요. 당신의 의견을 듣고 싶어 했죠. '나는 많이 알지 못해'라고 하면서 마음을 바꾸기도 했어요. 재밌는 건, 제가 가르치던 수업에서 '빠르게 생각하고 느리게 생각하기'에 대해 이야기할 때, 어떤 사람이 그 안에 있는 많은 연구들이 재현되지 않았다고 언급했어요.
text_zh: 他这个人特别谦虚，是真心想听你的想法。他经常说"我懂的不多"，而且很愿意改变自己的观点。有意思的是，我在讲《思考，快与慢》(Thinking, Fast and Slow)那门课的时候，有学生问到这本书里提到的很多研究后来都没能重现出来。
text_es: Era súper humilde, de verdad quería escuchar lo que pensabas. Decía 'No sé mucho', y podía cambiar de opinión sin problema. Es curioso, me preguntaron en una clase que estaba dando sobre pensar rápido y despacio (thinking fast and slow) y alguien comentó que había muchos estudios ahí que al final no se pudieron replicar.
context: Lenny asks Annie about lessons she learned from her friendship with Daniel Kahneman, the Nobel Prize-winning psychologist who recently passed away. Annie reflects on Kahneman's remarkable humility despite his enormous influence and intellect. She explains how he genuinely wanted to hear others' opinions and was willing to change his mind. She gives an example of how when studies from his famous book didn't replicate in later research, he was the first to acknowledge this rather than defending his previous work.
vocabulary_highlights: didn't end up replicating

speaker: Annie Duke
text: But the thing about Danny was when you talked about it, he was the first one to tell you, 'I wish priming wasn't in the book. It doesn't replicate.' He was just so open-minded to the idea that he knows what he knows now, but he knows that he doesn't know everything.
text_ko: 근데 대니에 대해 말하자면, 그 얘기가 나오면 제일 먼저 “프라이밍(priming)은 책에 안 넣었으면 좋았을 텐데. 재현(replicate)이 안 돼요.”라고 말해주던 사람이었어요. 그는 지금 자기가 아는 건 알고 있지만, 모든 걸 아는 건 아니라고 인정하는 데 아주 열린 마음을 가진 사람이었어요.
text_zh: 但是丹尼这个人就是这样，你要是跟他聊起这个话题，他第一个就会告诉你："我真希望当初没把启动效应(priming)写进书里，这个实验根本重现不了。" 他就是这么开放的心态，知道自己现在懂什么，但也清楚自己不是什么都懂。
text_es: Pero lo que pasaba con Danny es que cuando hablabas del tema, él era el primero en decirte: "Ojalá no hubiera incluido lo del priming en el libro. No se puede replicar." Tenía una mentalidad súper abierta, sabía lo que sabía en ese momento, pero también sabía que no lo sabía todo.
context: Annie continues sharing her memories of Daniel Kahneman and his remarkable intellectual humility. She contrasts his approach with other researchers who become defensive when their work doesn't replicate in later studies. Annie explains how Kahneman was refreshingly open about acknowledging when his previous research, including concepts like priming that were featured in his famous book, turned out not to be reproducible. This demonstrated his commitment to truth over protecting his reputation.
vocabulary_highlights: it doesn't replicate, open-minded

speaker: Annie Duke
text: I think the answer is a lot with a big if, with an if you can get people to do it. And I think that's where the issue comes in. Now, the good news is that you can then reverse that and say if I'm willing to do it, think about what an edge I'm going to have over people who aren't willing to do it, right?
text_ko: 제 생각엔 가능성이 큰데, 다만 큰 '만약' 하나가 있어요 — 사람들을 그걸 하게 만들 수 있느냐는 조건이요. 그게 바로 문제가 되는 부분이라고 생각해요. 다행인 건, 관점을 바꿔서 내가 기꺼이 한다면 하지 않으려는 사람들에 비해 어떤 경쟁 우위(competitive edge)를 가지게 될지 생각해 볼 수 있다는 거예요, 그렇죠?
text_zh: 我觉得答案是肯定的，但有个大前提，就是你得能让大家都去做这件事。我觉得问题就出在这儿。不过好消息是，你可以反过来想，如果我愿意去做，想想看我会比那些不愿意做的人有多大优势，对吧？
text_es: Creo que la respuesta es "muchísimo, pero con un gran 'si'", con un "si logras que la gente lo haga". Y creo que ahí está el problema. Ahora, lo bueno es que puedes darle la vuelta y decir: si yo estoy dispuesto a hacerlo, imagínate la ventaja que voy a tener sobre los que no están dispuestos a hacerlo, ¿no?
context: Lenny asks Annie how much better someone can actually get at making decisions if they study and apply decision-making frameworks intensively. Annie explains that people can improve dramatically at decision-making, but there's a big caveat - they have to actually implement the techniques, which most people don't do. She references Daniel Kahneman's research showing hiring success rates improved from 50% to 65% when structured processes were used. However, she notes this creates an opportunity for those willing to put in the effort.
vocabulary_highlights: what an edge, willing to do it

speaker: Annie Pearl
speaker_expertise: Product Strategy, Marketing Strategy, Product Management
text: Strategy is really just an integrated set of choices that outline how you're going to win in whatever marketplace you choose. And so, a good product strategy is going to answer questions like what's your winning aspiration? But maybe more importantly, where are you going to play? What are the markets you're going to go after? What are the segments of those markets? What are the personas in the segments of those markets? And then, how are you going to win with a target audience?
text_ko: 전략(strategy)은 결국 어떤 시장을 선택하든 그 안에서 어떻게 이길지에 대한 선택들을 통합해 정리한 거예요. 그래서 좋은 제품 전략(product strategy)은 '우리의 승리 목표(winning aspiration)는 무엇인가요?' 같은 질문에 답해야 해요. 더 중요한 건 '어디서 경쟁할 건가요?' 즉, 어떤 시장(markets)을 공략할 건지, 그 시장의 어떤 세그먼트(segments)를 노릴 건지, 그 세그먼트 안에 어떤 페르소나(personas)가 있는지를 정하는 거예요. 그리고 나서 특정 타깃(target audience)과 어떻게 이길지에 대한 계획도 있어야 해요.
text_zh: 战略说白了就是一套完整的选择，告诉你在你选定的市场里怎么赢。所以呢，一个好的产品战略得回答这些问题：你的制胜目标是什么？但更重要的可能是，你要在哪儿发力？你要攻哪些市场？这些市场里的哪些细分领域？这些细分领域里的目标用户画像(persona)是什么样的？然后，你怎么在这些目标受众那里获胜？
text_es: La estrategia es básicamente un conjunto integrado de decisiones que define cómo vas a ganar en el mercado que elijas. Entonces, una buena estrategia de producto va a responder preguntas como: ¿cuál es tu aspiración ganadora? Pero quizás más importante aún: ¿dónde vas a jugar? ¿A qué mercados te vas a dirigir? ¿Cuáles son los segmentos de esos mercados? ¿Cuáles son los perfiles (personas) dentro de los segmentos de esos mercados? Y después, ¿cómo vas a ganar con tu audiencia objetivo?
context: Lenny asks Annie about how to prioritize product work when getting requests from salespeople, founders, and various stakeholders. Annie explains her framework for prioritization, which starts with having a clear product strategy. She references the 'Playing to Win' framework that defines strategy as an integrated set of choices for winning in your chosen marketplace. This framework forces clarity on where you'll play and where you won't, helping product teams focus on delivering value for specific personas rather than trying to build for everyone.
vocabulary_highlights: integrated set of choices, winning aspiration, segments of those markets

speaker: Annie Pearl
speaker_expertise: Product Strategy, Marketing Strategy, Product Management
text: I think the best example I can give is there's lots of small businesses and solopreneurs who would love us to have a Venmo integration. We have a PayPal integration. But our target market that we're really trying to go after as our primary persona are as I've mentioned, these sort of core ICPs within organizations. So, sales teams, recruiting teams, customer success teams. And so, it doesn't make sense within those personas to pursue something like a Venmo integration.
text_ko: 가장 좋은 예로는, Venmo 연동(Venmo integration)을 원하시는 소규모 사업체들(small businesses)과 1인 창업자들(solopreneurs)이 많다는 거예요. 저희는 이미 PayPal 연동(PayPal integration)을 제공하고 있는데, 사실 저희가 실제로 주력으로 공략하려는 타깃 시장(target market), 즉 제가 언급한 조직 내 핵심 ICP(ideal customer profile)는 영업팀(sales teams), 채용팀(recruiting teams), 고객 성공팀(customer success teams) 같은 팀들이에요. 그래서 그런 페르소나들 입장에서는 Venmo 연동 같은 걸 굳이 추진하는 게 합리적이지 않아요.
text_zh: 我觉得最好的例子就是，有很多小企业和个人创业者特别希望我们能接入Venmo。我们现在有PayPal的集成。但我们真正想要抓住的目标市场，也就是我们的核心用户画像(primary persona)，就像我刚才提到的，是那些机构里的核心理想客户画像(core ICPs)。比如说销售团队、招聘团队、客户成功团队。所以对于这些用户群体来说，搞什么Venmo集成根本就不合适。
text_es: Creo que el mejor ejemplo que puedo dar es que hay muchísimas pequeñas empresas y emprendedores independientes (solopreneurs) que les encantaría que tuviéramos una integración con Venmo. Tenemos integración con PayPal. Pero nuestro mercado objetivo, al que realmente estamos apuntando como nuestro cliente ideal principal (primary persona), son como mencioné, estos perfiles centrales (core ICPs) dentro de las organizaciones. O sea, equipos de ventas, equipos de reclutamiento, equipos de éxito del cliente. Entonces, no tiene sentido para esos perfiles ir tras algo como una integración con Venmo.
context: Lenny asks Annie for an example of a feature that people keep requesting but hasn't been built due to strategic focus. Annie explains how Calendly receives requests for a Venmo integration from small businesses and solopreneurs, but they've chosen not to build it. This is because their strategic focus is on serving core ICPs (Ideal Customer Profiles) within organizations - specifically sales, recruiting, and customer success teams - rather than individual freelancers who might use Venmo for payments.
vocabulary_highlights: solopreneurs, core ICPs

speaker: Annie Pearl
speaker_expertise: Product Strategy, Marketing Strategy, Product Management
text: Something we've done over the last year is really kind of moved to a model of talking about dates and promising and committing to dates that are within our control. And so, if you think about the product development life cycle, we can commit to a discovery effort of doing research around a certain problem space and we can have a general sense of when we know that effort's going to conclude.
text_ko: 지난 1년 동안 저희가 해온 것 중 하나는, 통제할 수 있는 날짜(일정)에 대해서만 얘기하고 그 날짜를 약속(커밋)하는 방식으로 바뀐 거예요. 제품 개발 라이프사이클(product development life cycle)을 생각해 보면, 특정 문제 영역(problem space)에 대한 리서치를 하는 디스커버리 노력(discovery effort)은 약속할 수 있고 그 노력이 언제 끝날지에 대해선 대략적인 감을 잡을 수 있어요.
text_zh: 过去一年我们做了个调整，就是只承诺那些我们能把控的时间节点。你想想产品开发这个流程，我们可以承诺去做某个问题领域的调研工作，大概什么时候能出结果我们心里是有数的。
text_es: Lo que hemos hecho durante el último año es cambiar hacia un modelo donde hablamos de fechas y nos comprometemos con plazos que realmente están bajo nuestro control. Entonces, si piensas en el ciclo de desarrollo de producto, podemos comprometernos con un esfuerzo de descubrimiento para investigar cierto espacio de problemas y tener una idea general de cuándo sabemos que ese esfuerzo va a terminar.
context: Lenny asks Annie about how Calendly does planning and roadmaps. Annie describes their approach to estimation and delivery commitments, which focuses on only committing to work phases that are within their control. Rather than promising delivery dates for projects six months out when they haven't done discovery work yet, they break work into phases: discovery, solutioning, build, and launch. They only commit to dates for the immediate phase in front of them, making more realistic and achievable commitments.
vocabulary_highlights: within our control, general sense

speaker: Annie Pearl
speaker_expertise: Product Strategy, Marketing Strategy, Product Management
text: When you transition from PLG to sales led or adding this direct sales motion, the buyer is usually just the department head. It's the head of sales, it's the head of rev ops, it's the head of recruiting and it's not a senior person in IT or the CIO. And so, selling into this audience is different than selling into IT.
text_ko: 제품 주도 성장(PLG)에서 영업 주도(sales-led)로 전환하거나 직접 영업(direct sales motion)을 추가하면, 구매자는 보통 부서장 한 명이에요. 영업 책임자나 레브옵스(rev ops) 책임자, 채용 책임자 같은 분들이고 IT의 고위 담당자나 최고정보책임자(CIO)는 아닌 경우가 많아요. 그래서 이런 대상에게 파는 방식은 IT에 파는 방식과 달라요.
text_zh: 当你从PLG转向销售主导，或者加入直销模式(direct sales motion)的时候，买单的人通常就是部门负责人。可能是销售总监、收入运营总监(rev ops)、招聘总监，而不是IT部门的高级人员或者CIO。所以说，向这些人卖东西和向IT部门卖是完全不一样的。
text_es: Cuando haces la transición de PLG a un enfoque liderado por ventas o agregas este movimiento de ventas directas, el comprador normalmente es solo el jefe del departamento. Es el director de ventas, el jefe de operaciones de ingresos (rev ops), el director de reclutamiento, y no es alguien senior en IT o el CIO. Entonces, vender a esta audiencia es muy diferente que vender a IT.
context: Lenny asks Annie about hiring salespeople when transitioning from a product-led growth model to adding sales. Annie explains the importance of matching sales reps to the target buyer persona. When companies first add sales to a PLG motion, the buyers are typically department heads (sales, recruiting, customer success) rather than IT executives or CIOs. This requires salespeople with experience selling to departmental leaders, not those who specialize in selling complex enterprise software to IT decision makers.
vocabulary_highlights: sales led motion, rev ops

speaker: Annie Pearl
speaker_expertise: Product Strategy, Marketing Strategy, Product Management
text: Most people probably think about Calendly as the scheduling link and really for individual users to reduce the back and forth of email and scheduling. So, they think of that one-on-one use case and I think people would be surprised to learn that our team's business, so multiple users in an organization who want to collaboratively schedule together is growing much faster than our solo user business.
text_ko: 대부분 사람들은 아마 Calendly를 스케줄링 링크(scheduling link) 정도로만 생각하고, 개별 사용자가 이메일 왕복과 일정 조율을 줄이기 위해 쓰는 도구로 여겨요. 그래서 1:1(one-on-one) 사용 사례만 떠올리는데, 사실 조직 내 여러 사용자가 함께 일정 조율을 하는 팀 비즈니스(team business)가 개인 사용자(solo user) 비즈니스보다 훨씬 빠르게 성장하고 있다는 사실에 놀랄 거예요.
text_zh: 大部分人可能觉得Calendly就是个约会链接，主要是帮个人用户减少那些来回发邮件约时间的麻烦。所以他们想到的就是一对一约会这种场景，但我觉得大家会很意外地发现，我们的团队业务——就是一个公司里多个用户想要一起协作排期的这块业务，增长速度其实比我们的个人用户业务要快得多。
text_es: La mayoría de la gente probablemente piensa en Calendly como el enlace para agendar citas y realmente para usuarios individuales que quieren evitar ese ir y venir de emails para coordinar horarios. O sea, piensan en ese caso de uso uno a uno, y creo que la gente se sorprendería al saber que nuestro negocio de equipos, donde múltiples usuarios en una organización quieren programar reuniones de forma colaborativa, está creciendo mucho más rápido que nuestro negocio de usuarios individuales.
context: Lenny asks Annie what would surprise people about how Calendly grows. Annie explains that while most people think of Calendly as a tool for individual scheduling to eliminate email back-and-forth, the reality is different. Their fastest growing segment is actually teams business - where multiple users in an organization collaboratively schedule together. This represents their future growth direction: supporting teams, departments, and eventually multi-departmental deployments across entire organizations.
vocabulary_highlights: back and forth, collaboratively schedule

speaker: Annie Pearl
speaker_expertise: Product Strategy, Marketing Strategy, Product Management
text: The folks who started it all was Google, with the Google APM program. And Meta obviously has a pretty strong robust APM program. But as I mentioned around Box, I think those are obviously very, very competitive and most people want to get into them. It may be better to try and find a company like Box or a company that's a bit earlier stage, not as scaled to think about looking at those APM programs.
text_ko: 이걸 처음 시작한 건 구글의 APM 프로그램(Google APM program)이에요. 메타도 당연히 꽤 탄탄한 APM 프로그램(APM program)을 운영하고 있고요. 앞서 Box 얘기할 때 말했듯이, 그런 곳들은 경쟁이 워낙 치열해서 대부분 사람들이 들어가고 싶어 해요. 그래서 오히려 Box 같은 회사나 아직 규모가 크지 않은 초기 단계 회사에서 그런 APM 프로그램을 노려보는 게 더 나을 수도 있어요.
text_zh: 最早开始这个的是谷歌，搞了个谷歌APM项目。Meta显然也有个挺强的APM项目。但就像我刚才提到Box的情况，这些项目竞争都特别激烈，大家都想挤进去。可能更好的策略是去找像Box这样的公司，或者那些还在早期阶段、规模还没那么大的公司，去看看他们的APM项目(APM program)。
text_es: La gente que empezó todo esto fue Google, con su programa de APM de Google. Y Meta obviamente tiene un programa de APM bastante sólido y robusto. Pero como mencioné con lo de Box, creo que esos programas son obviamente súper competitivos y la mayoría de la gente quiere entrar ahí. Puede que sea mejor tratar de encontrar una empresa como Box o una compañía que esté en una etapa más temprana, que no sea tan grande, para considerar esos programas de APM.
context: Lenny asks Annie about specific APM (Associate Product Manager) programs she'd recommend for people trying to break into product management. Annie explains that while Google pioneered APM programs and Meta has strong programs, these are extremely competitive. She suggests looking at earlier-stage companies like Box that also have APM programs but may be more accessible than big tech companies, giving aspiring PMs better chances of breaking into product management.
vocabulary_highlights: pretty strong robust, not as scaled

speaker: Anton Osika
speaker_expertise: AI/ML Products, Growth Strategy, Team Building
text: I don't know about your mom, but my mom doesn't write code and almost all my friends throughout my life reached out for help. Like, 'Anton, I need to build something. How do I find a great software engineer?' And we are building for this 99% of the population who don't write code.
text_ko: 네 엄마는 어떨지 모르겠지만, 제 엄마는 코딩(coding)을 안 하시고, 지금까지 만난 거의 모든 친구들이 도움을 청하러 연락했어요. 친구들이 "안톤, 뭔가 만들고 싶은데, 훌륭한 소프트웨어 엔지니어(software engineer)는 어떻게 찾지?"라고 물어보곤 했어요. 우리는 코딩을 하지 않는 사람들 전체의 99%를 위해 이걸 만들고 있어요.
text_zh: 我不知道你妈妈怎么样，但我妈肯定不会写代码，我身边的朋友基本上都来找过我帮忙。就是那种"安东，我想做个什么东西，上哪儿找靠谱的程序员啊？"我们做的产品就是为了这99%不会写代码的普通人。
text_es: No sé tu mamá, pero la mía no programa y casi todos mis amigos a lo largo de mi vida me han pedido ayuda. Como que "Antón, necesito crear algo. ¿Cómo encuentro un buen desarrollador de software?" Y estamos construyendo para ese 99% de la población que no programa.
context: Lenny asks Anton to explain what Lovable is and why they're building it. Anton describes Lovable as a personal AI software engineer where you describe an idea and get a fully working product. He explains their motivation for creating this tool - to serve the vast majority of people who have ideas but can't code and struggle to find good software engineers to build their products.
vocabulary_highlights: reached out for help, 99% of the population

speaker: Anton Osika
speaker_expertise: AI/ML Products, Growth Strategy, Team Building
text: The best word for a great product is that it's lovable. A lot of jargon that I like to use to emphasize what we should be striving for is building a minimum lovable product and then building a lovable product and then building an absolutely lovable product. So I took that jargon with me in the company name.
text_ko: 훌륭한 제품을 한마디로 표현할 때 가장 좋은 단어는 '사랑받는(lovable)'이에요. 제가 우리가 지향해야 할 걸 강조하려고 자주 쓰는 전문 용어가 있는데, '최소로 사랑받을 수 있는 제품(minimum lovable product)'을 만들고, 그다음엔 '사랑받는 제품(lovable product)'을 만들고, 결국엔 '완전히 사랑받는 제품(absolutely lovable product)'을 만드는 거예요. 그래서 그 표현을 회사 이름에도 담았어요.
text_zh: 要形容一个出色的产品，我觉得最好的词就是"让人爱不释手"。我特别喜欢用一个说法来强调我们应该追求的目标，就是先做出一个最小可爱产品(minimum lovable product)，然后做成可爱产品(lovable product)，最后做成绝对可爱产品(absolutely lovable product)。所以我把这个理念带到了公司名字里。
text_es: La mejor palabra para describir un gran producto es que sea adorable. Hay mucha jerga que me gusta usar para enfatizar hacia qué deberíamos apuntar: crear un producto mínimo adorable (minimum lovable product), luego un producto adorable (lovable product) y después un producto absolutamente adorable (absolutely lovable product). Así que me llevé esa jerga conmigo al nombre de la empresa.
context: Lenny asks Anton how he decided on the name 'Lovable' for his company, commenting that it's so sweet. Anton explains his philosophy around product development, describing his belief that the best descriptor for a great product is that it's 'lovable.' He shares his framework of progressing from minimum lovable product to absolutely lovable product, which influenced his choice of company name.
vocabulary_highlights: a lot of jargon, striving for, took that jargon with me

speaker: Anton Osika
speaker_expertise: AI/ML Products, Growth Strategy, Team Building
text: Doing a bit of everything. Being a generalist, I think much more important than it used to be. If I'm putting together a product team today, I would really obsess about getting as many skill sets as possible for each person I hire.
text_ko: 이것저것 조금씩 해보는 거예요. 제너럴리스트(generalist)가 예전보다 훨씬 더 중요해진 것 같아요. 지금 프로덕트 팀(product team)을 꾸린다면, 뽑는 사람 한 명 한 명이 가능한 한 많은 스킬셋(skill sets)을 갖추도록 정말 집착할 거예요.
text_zh: 什么都会一点儿。现在当个多面手，我觉得比以前重要多了。如果我现在要组建一个产品团队，我会特别在意每个招进来的人都尽可能掌握更多技能。
text_es: Hacer de todo un poco. Ser generalista, creo que es mucho más importante ahora que antes. Si estoy armando un equipo de producto hoy en día, me obsesionaría con conseguir la mayor cantidad de habilidades posibles en cada persona que contrate.
context: Lenny asks Anton about what jobs will be more important and what skills will be less important as AI tools like Lovable become more prevalent. Anton responds that being a generalist who can do multiple things is becoming much more valuable than specialization. He emphasizes that when building product teams now, he would focus intensely on hiring people with diverse skill sets rather than narrow specialists.
vocabulary_highlights: doing a bit of everything, really obsess about, as many skill sets as possible

speaker: Anton Osika
speaker_expertise: AI/ML Products, Growth Strategy, Team Building
text: Explaining exactly what you expect and what you're not getting is even more important with AI than with the humans. So I'm going into hooking up more of the actual functionality, but first I'll actually show you something.
text_ko: 사람보다 인공지능(AI)에게는 기대하는 바와 받지 못하고 있는 부분을 정확히 설명하는 게 훨씬 더 중요해요. 그래서 실제 기능들을 더 연동하려고 하는데, 먼저 뭔가 하나 보여드릴게요.
text_zh: 跟AI说清楚你想要什么、现在缺什么，这比跟人沟通还要重要。所以接下来我要连接更多实际功能，不过先给你们演示点东西看看。
text_es: Explicar exactamente qué esperas y qué no estás obteniendo es aún más importante con la IA que con las personas. Así que me voy a meter de lleno en conectar más de la funcionalidad real, pero primero te voy a enseñar algo.
context: During a live demo where Anton is showing how to build an Airbnb clone with Lovable, Lenny comments on how being a good product manager with clear communication skills is important when working with AI tools. Anton responds that being precise about expectations and clearly explaining what's working versus what's not working is actually more critical when working with AI than with human engineers.
vocabulary_highlights: exactly what you expect, hooking up, actual functionality

speaker: Anton Osika
speaker_expertise: AI/ML Products, Growth Strategy, Team Building
text: These tools as we see here, they're already very good, it looks really good as well, but mainly I would say they're getting better very, very fast. And I'd say one of the bigger bottlenecks is now they're not integrated into the current way that you have your existing products and so on. But since they're getting better so fast, I think the best thing for people who are interested in this or interested in just being a part of the future economies, get your hands very dirty with these tools because being in the top 10% in using them is going to absolutely set you apart in the coming months and years.
text_ko: 여기 보시다시피 이 도구들은 이미 꽤 좋고 시각적으로도 훌륭해요. 무엇보다도 지금 아주, 정말 빠르게 좋아지고 있어요. 다만 지금 큰 병목 중 하나는 이 도구들이 기존 제품이나 현재의 운영 방식에 잘 통합(integrated)되어 있지 않다는 점이에요. 그런데 개선 속도가 워낙 빠르니, 이 분야에 관심이 있거나 앞으로의 경제(future economies)에 참여하고 싶은 분들은 직접 깊이 다뤄보는 게 가장 좋아요. 이 도구들을 잘 다루는 상위 10%(top 10%)에 들면 앞으로 몇 달, 몇 년 사이에 확실히 차별화될 거예요.
text_zh: 你看这些工具，现在已经很厉害了，效果也确实不错，但我觉得最主要的是它们进步得特别特别快。现在比较大的一个瓶颈就是，它们还没有很好地融入到你现有的产品体系里面。但是因为它们发展得这么快，我觉得对于那些对这个领域感兴趣的人，或者想要跟上未来经济趋势的人来说，最好的办法就是赶紧上手去用这些工具，因为如果你能做到使用水平排在前10%，那在接下来的几个月甚至几年里，你绝对会脱颖而出。
text_es: Estas herramientas, como vemos aquí, ya están muy buenas, se ven realmente bien, pero yo diría que lo más importante es que están mejorando súper rápido. Y creo que uno de los cuellos de botella más grandes es que todavía no están integradas con la forma actual en que tienes tus productos existentes y todo eso. Pero como están mejorando tan rápido, creo que lo mejor para la gente que esté interesada en esto o que quiera ser parte de las economías del futuro, es meterse de lleno con estas herramientas, porque estar en el top 10% usándolas te va a posicionar completamente diferente en los próximos meses y años.
context: After completing a demo where he built an Airbnb clone in minutes, Lenny marvels at what AI tools can now accomplish. Anton acknowledges that while these tools are already impressive, they're improving at an extremely rapid pace. He identifies integration with existing products as a current limitation, but strongly advises people to start using these tools extensively now, arguing that expertise with AI tools will be a major competitive advantage in the near future.
vocabulary_highlights: get your hands very dirty, absolutely set you apart, coming months and years

speaker: Anton Osika
speaker_expertise: AI/ML Products, Growth Strategy, Team Building
text: It takes a lot to master using tools like Lovable and being very curious and patient and we have something called chat mode where you can just ask to understand like, 'How does this work? I'm not getting what I want here, am I missing something? What should I do?' Is the best way to be productive is also one of the best ways to just learn about how software engineering works, which is you don't have to write the code anymore, but it is useful to understand how software engin- or how building products works. So I think that's the patience and curiosity is super useful.
text_ko: Lovable 같은 도구(Lovable)를 잘 다루려면 정말 많은 연습과 호기심, 인내가 필요해요. 그리고 '챗 모드(chat mode)'라는 기능이 있어서 "이게 어떻게 작동하죠? 원하는 게 안 나오는데 제가 뭘 놓치고 있나요? 어떻게 해야 하나요?"처럼 그냥 물어보면서 이해할 수 있어요. 생산적으로 일하는 가장 좋은 방법이자 소프트웨어 엔지니어링(software engineering)이 어떻게 돌아가는지 배우는 좋은 방법 중 하나는 더 이상 직접 코드를 써야 하는 건 아니지만, 그래도 소프트웨어 엔지니어링이나 제품 개발(product development)이 어떻게 이루어지는지 이해하는 게 유용하다는 점이에요. 그래서 인내심과 호기심이 정말 큰 도움이 된다고 생각해요.
text_zh: 要掌握Lovable这样的工具确实需要下不少功夫，得特别有好奇心和耐心。我们有个聊天模式(chat mode)，你可以直接问比如"这个怎么用啊？我怎么搞不出想要的效果，是不是漏了什么？我该怎么办？"这样既能提高效率，也是了解软件工程原理的最好方法之一。虽然现在不用自己写代码了，但懂得软件工程或者说产品开发的原理还是很有用的。所以我觉得保持耐心和好奇心真的很重要。
text_es: Para dominar herramientas como Lovable se necesita mucha curiosidad y paciencia, y tenemos algo que se llama modo chat (chat mode) donde simplemente puedes preguntar para entender, tipo: "¿Cómo funciona esto? No estoy consiguiendo lo que quiero, ¿se me está escapando algo? ¿Qué debería hacer?" Es la mejor manera de ser productivo y también una de las mejores formas de aprender cómo funciona la ingeniería de software, o sea, ya no tienes que escribir el código, pero sí es útil entender cómo funciona la ingeniería de software o cómo se construyen productos. Entonces creo que esa paciencia y curiosidad es súper valiosa.
context: Lenny asks Anton for the single most important tip he would give someone using Lovable for the first time. Anton emphasizes that mastering AI tools requires significant effort, curiosity, and patience. He recommends using Lovable's chat mode to ask questions when things aren't working as expected, explaining that this approach not only improves productivity but also helps users learn fundamental software engineering concepts without needing to write code themselves.
vocabulary_highlights: takes a lot to master, am I missing something, super useful

speaker: Anton Osika
speaker_expertise: AI/ML Products, Growth Strategy, Team Building
text: I think raw cognitive capability is the strongest, the strongest correlate of being at Lovable. But there is this startup mindset that I think is also very strong. Being much more interested in moving very fast and iterating fast, then having a lot of structure, a lot of process and thinking about the business as a whole. More than thinking about my specific profession, my specific craft that I'm seeing myself wanting to dig into on me.
text_ko: 제 생각에는 순수한 인지 능력(raw cognitive capability)이 러버블 단계(Lovable)에 있는 것과 가장 강한 상관관계가 있는 것 같아요. 하지만 스타트업 마인드셋(startup mindset)도 아주 강하다고 봐요. 많은 구조나 프로세스를 갖추는 것보다는 훨씬 더 빠르게 움직이고 빠르게 반복(iterate fast)하는 것에 더 관심이 있어요. 제 구체적인 직업이나 특정 기술을 더 깊이 파고들고 싶어 하는 것보다는요.
text_zh: 我觉得纯粹的认知能力是在Lovable最重要的素质。但还有一种创业心态(startup mindset)也特别关键。就是更愿意快速行动、快速迭代(iterating)，而不是搞一大堆架构啊、流程啊什么的，要从整个业务的角度去思考问题。不能只盯着自己那一亩三分地，只想着怎么在自己的专业领域里钻研。
text_es: Creo que la capacidad cognitiva pura es lo más importante, la correlación más fuerte para estar en Lovable. Pero también está esta mentalidad de startup que considero súper importante. Estar mucho más interesado en moverse muy rápido e iterar rápido, que en tener un montón de estructura, un montón de procesos y pensar en el negocio como un todo. Más que pensar en mi profesión específica, en mi área específica en la que me veo queriendo profundizar.
context: Lenny asks Anton what attributes are common among the people he's hired for his rapidly growing startup. Anton identifies raw cognitive ability as the strongest predictor of success at Lovable, but also emphasizes the importance of having a startup mindset. He describes this as preferring rapid iteration over heavy structure and processes, and thinking holistically about the business rather than focusing narrowly on one's specific professional role or craft.
vocabulary_highlights: raw cognitive capability, strongest correlate, startup mindset, dig into

speaker: Anuj Rathi
text: There are only three reasons why things do not happen the way you want them to happen as a leader. You can look at a person, and you would say either that person can't do, which is a capability issue, or they won't do, which is a motivation or an alignment issue, or they were not set up to do, which is really your problem that you didn't set up the ways of working now design properly.
text_ko: 리더로서 일이 원하는 대로 안 되는 건 세 가지 이유밖에 없어요. 첫째, 그 사람이 그 일을 못해서, 즉 능력 문제(capability issue)이에요. 둘째, 그 사람이 하려 하지 않아서, 즉 동기나 조율(alignment) 문제예요. 셋째, 그 사람이 하도록 환경이나 시스템을 못 만들어줘서인데, 이건 당신 책임이에요 — 업무 방식(ways of working)이나 설계(design)를 제대로 해놓지 않았기 때문이에요.
text_zh: 作为领导，事情没有按你预期发展，无非就三个原因。你看一个人，要么是他能力不行，做不了；要么是他不想做，动机或者目标不一致的问题；要么就是你没给他搭好台子，工作流程和机制设计有问题，这其实是你自己的责任。
text_es: Solo hay tres razones por las que las cosas no salen como quieres cuando eres líder. Puedes mirar a una persona y decir: o esa persona no puede hacerlo, que es un tema de capacidades, o no quiere hacerlo, que es un problema de motivación o alineación, o no se le dieron las condiciones para hacerlo, y ahí el problema es tuyo porque no diseñaste bien los procesos de trabajo desde el principio.
context: Lenny asks Anuj about leadership and managing teams effectively. Anuj explains his framework for diagnosing performance issues when team members aren't delivering expected results. He breaks down the root causes into three categories: capability gaps (can't do), motivation/alignment problems (won't do), or systemic setup failures (weren't set up to do). This framework helps leaders identify whether they need to coach, realign, or fix organizational processes.
vocabulary_highlights: ways of working, set up to do, alignment issue

speaker: Anuj Rathi
text: One of the things that I realized once we started working with the products is that product managers and generally, companies are too engrossed in thinking about... because they are very close to the product. It's close to their heart, and they're looking at it all the time. They're looking at a lot of minor nuances in terms of how this works and feels, and almost inherent into this is the bias that everybody is thinking about this product all day, all the time, and so on, and so forth.
text_ko: 제품(product)과 함께 일해보면서 깨달은 것 중 하나는 프로덕트 매니저(product manager)들이나 회사들이 제품에 너무 몰입해 있다는 거예요. 제품이 워낙 가깝고 마음에 닿아 있어서 항상 들여다보니까 작동 방식이나 사용감 같은 사소한 뉘앙스까지 계속 신경 쓰게 되죠. 그리고 거기에는 거의 본질적으로 '모두가 하루 종일, 항상 이 제품만 생각하고 있을 거다'라는 편향이 깔려 있어요, 등등.
text_zh: 我发现一个问题，就是当我们开始接触这些产品的时候，产品经理们，包括整个公司，都太沉浸在产品里了...因为他们跟产品贴得太近，把产品当心头肉一样，天天盯着看。他们会去扣很多细节，比如这个功能怎么用啊，体验感觉怎么样啊，这样就不知不觉陷入了一个误区，觉得所有人都会像他们一样，一天到晚想着这个产品。
text_es: Una de las cosas de las que me di cuenta cuando empezamos a trabajar con los productos es que los product managers y, en general, las empresas se obsesionan demasiado pensando en... porque están muy pegados al producto. Lo sienten como algo muy suyo, y lo están viendo todo el tiempo. Se fijan en un montón de detalles pequeños sobre cómo funciona y se siente, y casi sin darse cuenta caen en el sesgo (bias) de pensar que todo el mundo está pensando en este producto las 24 horas del día, que es su prioridad número uno, y así sucesivamente.
context: Lenny asks Anuj about his approach to building user experiences for new users. Anuj explains a common bias that product managers develop - they become so immersed in their product that they assume users share their level of engagement and understanding. He argues this creates a disconnect because most consumers don't think about any single product constantly and need to be approached differently when they first encounter a product.
vocabulary_highlights: too engrossed in, close to their heart, inherent into this

speaker: Anuj Rathi
text: There's very interesting insight that I heard from Scott Belsky from Adobe, and then now, he's doing very interesting stuff, and that stayed with me which was you have to think about users on modern internet consumers having three attributes. So they are lazy, they are vain, and they're selfish.
text_ko: Adobe의 Scott Belsky에게서 들은 흥미로운 인사이트가 있어요. 지금 그가 하는 일도 정말 흥미로운데, 그가 한 말 중 하나가 오래 남았어요. 현대 인터넷 소비자(modern internet consumers)를 생각할 때 세 가지 특성이 있다고 보라는 거예요. 즉, 게으르고, 허영심이 많고, 이기적이에요.
text_zh: 我听Adobe的Scott Belsky说过一个特别有意思的观点，他现在在做的东西也很有意思，这个观点一直让我印象深刻。他说你得这样看现在的互联网用户，他们有三个特点：懒、爱慕虚荣，还有就是自私。
text_es: Hay una reflexión muy interesante que escuché de Scott Belsky de Adobe, que ahora está haciendo cosas súper interesantes, y se me quedó grabada: tienes que pensar en los usuarios, en los consumidores modernos de internet, como si tuvieran tres características. O sea, son flojos, son vanidosos y son egoístas.
context: Anuj continues explaining his philosophy for designing products for new users. He shares a framework from Adobe's Scott Belsky that characterizes internet users with three key traits. According to this framework, users are 'lazy' (don't want to spend time learning), 'vain' (resistant to changing existing habits), and 'selfish' (need clear personal benefits). This insight helps product managers design onboarding experiences that account for user reluctance and skepticism.
vocabulary_highlights: stayed with me, modern internet consumers

speaker: Anuj Rathi
text: We are product managers, and we are in the business of influence. Users are doing something, and now we want them to do something else. Our engineers are doing something, and now we want to influence them into building something fast. Really, leadership has some plans. We'll influence them to, essentially, look at a plan, and basically, sign off, and do something else. We are in the business of influence, and you are doing this all the time internally.
text_ko: 우리는 프로덕트 매니저(product managers)로서 영향력을 행사하는 일을 해요. 사용자들은 지금 어떤 행동을 하고 있고, 우리는 그들이 다른 행동을 하도록 유도하려고 해요. 엔지니어들(engineers)은 지금 뭔가를 하고 있고, 우리는 그들을 설득해 빠르게 뭔가를 만들게 하려 해요. 사실 리더십(leadership)은 이미 계획이 있고, 우리가 하는 건 결국 그들이 그 계획을 보고 승인(sign off)해서 다른 일을 하게 만드는 거예요. 우리는 영향력을 발휘하는 일을 하고 있고, 여러분도 사내에서 늘 이 일을 하고 있어요.
text_zh: 我们是产品经理，说白了就是干影响别人这一行的。用户现在在做这个，我们想让他们去做那个。我们的工程师现在在搞这个，我们得想办法影响他们快点把东西做出来。还有领导层那边，他们有自己的计划，我们得影响他们看看我们的方案，基本上就是让他们点个头，然后去做别的事儿。我们就是干影响这一行的，而且你在公司内部天天都在做这种事。
text_es: Somos product managers, y nuestro negocio es la influencia. Los usuarios están haciendo algo, y ahora queremos que hagan otra cosa. Nuestros ingenieros están haciendo algo, y queremos influenciarlos para que construyan algo rápido. En realidad, el liderazgo tiene ciertos planes. Los vamos a influenciar para que, básicamente, revisen un plan, le den el visto bueno, y hagan algo diferente. Estamos en el negocio de la influencia, y tú estás haciendo esto todo el tiempo internamente.
context: Lenny asks Anuj about effective messaging and value propositions for users. Anuj reframes the entire role of product management as fundamentally being about influence - not just influencing users to adopt products, but also influencing engineers to build features quickly and leadership to approve plans. He argues that viewing product management through this lens of influence helps PMs think more strategically about how they approach all their relationships.
vocabulary_highlights: in the business of influence, sign off
topics: Product Management, Leadership & Management, Communication Skills

speaker: Anuj Rathi
text: The other part that I found interesting here is that I really truly believe in the power of three. So I actually ask my teams to write three press releases, alternative and divergent like, 'What if we...' Suppose you're launching a membership program. So, instead of two tiers, let's do three tiers, or for example, let's take another one which is instead of building a membership, let's build up tiering pricing program with membership points.
text_ko: 여기서 제가 흥미롭게 본 또 하나는, 저는 정말로 '세의 힘'을 믿는다는 거예요. 그래서 팀들에게는 '만약 우리가 이랬다면…' 같은 식으로 대안적이고 서로 다른 관점에서 보도자료(press releases) 세 가지를 써보라고 요청해요. 예를 들어 멤버십 프로그램(membership program)을 런칭한다고 치면, 티어(tiers)를 두 개로 하지 말고 세 개로 해보자고 하거나, 멤버십을 만드는 대신 티어 기반 가격제(tiered pricing program)에 멤버십 포인트(membership points)를 도입해보자는 식이에요.
text_zh: 还有一点我觉得特别有意思，就是我真的很相信"三"的力量。所以我会让团队写三个不同的新闻稿，每个都是完全不同的思路，就像"如果我们这样做会怎样..."比如说你要推出会员项目吧，那与其只做两个等级，咱们就做三个等级，或者换个思路，与其做普通会员制，不如搞个分层定价的积分会员制。
text_es: Lo otro que me parece súper interesante es que realmente creo en el poder del tres. Entonces lo que hago es pedirles a mis equipos que escriban tres comunicados de prensa, pero alternativos y divergentes, como "¿Y si...?" Supongamos que van a lanzar un programa de membresía. Entonces, en lugar de dos niveles, hagamos tres niveles, o por ejemplo, tomemos otra opción que sería en lugar de crear una membresía, armemos un programa de precios escalonados con puntos de membresía.
context: Lenny asks about how Anuj operationalizes the 'working backwards' process from Amazon's playbook. Beyond writing a single press release, Anuj explains his approach of creating three divergent press releases for any major product decision. Each press release explores a fundamentally different strategic direction - for example, when launching a membership program, one might explore different tier structures while another might explore a completely different approach like points-based pricing.
vocabulary_highlights: power of three, alternative and divergent, tiering pricing program

speaker: Anuj Rathi
text: Unless you really... and I'm not saying you need to be an authority of that. Either you are very, very good at that, or you have built partnerships, and have run your ideas or product through those people and gotten weighted from them, and finally made a decision around that part, I don't think you'll be very successful.
text_ko: 솔직히 말해서... 제가 말하는 건 그 분야의 권위자(authority)가 될 필요는 없다는 거예요. 그걸 정말, 정말 잘하든가, 아니면 파트너십(partnerships)을 잘 구축해서 아이디어나 제품을 그분들한테 시험해 보고 피드백(feedback)을 충분히 받아 그 의견을 반영해 최종 결정을 내리지 않으면 성공하기 어렵다고 생각해요.
text_zh: 除非你真的...我不是说你必须是那方面的权威啊。要么你在那方面特别特别厉害，要么你建立了合作关系，把你的想法或产品拿给那些人过过眼，听听他们的意见，最后在那个环节做决定，不然的话，我觉得你很难成功。
text_es: A menos que realmente... y no digo que tengas que ser un experto en eso. O eres muy, muy bueno en eso, or has construido alianzas estratégicas (partnerships), y has pasado tus ideas o producto por esas personas y has obtenido su opinión fundamentada, y finalmente has tomado una decisión basada en eso, no creo que vayas a tener mucho éxito.
context: Lenny asks about Anuj's philosophy that product managers should be more 'full-stack' than most currently are. Anuj explains that successful PMs must either develop deep expertise across multiple disciplines (marketing, engineering, business) or build strong partnerships with experts in those areas. He emphasizes that PMs can't succeed by focusing only on their narrow product area - they need to understand and influence the full ecosystem that makes products successful.
vocabulary_highlights: authority of that, built partnerships, run your ideas through, gotten weighted from them

speaker: Anuj Rathi
text: So we essentially saw that if a startup actually usually wants to do a bunch of things across the border, there's always like, 'Hey, I should be investing in tech debt or building core platforms. That would really help my product in the long term. That's super important,' and that's my engineering managers and largely, people asking for that bandwidth.
text_ko: 결국 우리가 본 건, 스타트업이 여러 분야에서 동시에 뭔가를 하려고 하면 늘 “기술 부채(tech debt)에 투자하거나 코어 플랫폼(core platforms)을 만들어야 해. 장기적으로 제품에 큰 도움이 되고, 이건 정말 중요해”라는 얘기가 나온다는 거예요. 주로 엔지니어링 매니저들(engineering managers)이나 그런 여력(bandwidth)을 요구하는 분들이죠.
text_zh: 所以我们基本上发现，如果一个初创公司想要跨境做很多事情，总是会有这样的声音：'嘿，我应该投资技术债务(tech debt)或者搭建核心平台。这对我的产品长远发展真的很有帮助，超级重要。'而且我的工程经理们，还有很多人都在要这个资源。
text_es: Entonces básicamente vimos que si una startup quiere hacer muchas cosas a nivel internacional, siempre surge como "Oye, debería estar invirtiendo en deuda técnica (tech debt) o construyendo plataformas centrales. Eso realmente ayudaría a mi producto a largo plazo. Es súper importante," y esos son mis gerentes de ingeniería y en general, la gente pidiendo ese ancho de banda (bandwidth).
context: Lenny asks Anuj to explain his 'four BB framework' for product strategy. Anuj describes how startups typically face competing priorities across different types of work. He explains that engineering teams often push for technical infrastructure improvements and paying down tech debt, arguing these investments will benefit products long-term, while product managers want to focus on feature development and user-facing improvements. This tension creates the need for a strategic framework to allocate resources.
vocabulary_highlights: across the border, tech debt, core platforms, asking for that bandwidth
topics: Product Management, Strategy & Planning, Leadership & Management

speaker: Aparna Chennapragada
text: I have a cheesy Chrome extension. Literally whenever I open a new tab, it just says, how can you use AI to do what you're going to do right now? It's very cheesy, but it kind of helps to pause and think, 'Oh, what am I trying to do here?'
text_ko: 저는 약간 유치한 크롬 확장 프로그램(Chrome extension)을 하나 써요. 새 탭을 열 때마다 '지금 하려는 일을 인공지능(AI)으로 어떻게 활용할 수 있을까?'라고 딱 떠요. 좀 유치하긴 한데, 잠깐 멈춰서 '아, 내가 지금 하려는 게 뭐지?' 생각하게 해줘서 의외로 도움이 돼요.
text_zh: 我装了个特别俗的Chrome插件。每次打开新标签页的时候，它就问你：你能不能用AI来做你现在要做的事？虽然很俗，但确实能让你停下来想想："嗯，我现在到底要干什么？"
text_es: Tengo una extensión de Chrome súper cursi. Literalmente cada vez que abro una pestaña nueva, me pregunta: ¿cómo puedes usar IA para hacer lo que vas a hacer ahora mismo? Es súper cursi, pero la verdad es que me ayuda a pausar y pensar: "A ver, ¿qué es lo que estoy tratando de hacer aquí?"
context: Lenny asks Aparna about how she stays current with AI capabilities and overcomes old assumptions about what AI tools can or cannot do. Aparna explains that she built a simple Chrome extension that prompts her to consider using AI for whatever task she's about to do whenever she opens a new browser tab. She describes this as part of her experiment to become more 'AI-pilled' and develop reflexive AI usage habits both at work and in her personal life.
vocabulary_highlights: cheesy, AI-pilled, reflexive AI usage

speaker: Aparna Chennapragada
text: If you're not prototyping and building to see what you want to build, I think you're doing it wrong. It becomes even more important to have that editorial and taste-making at the heart of it because, otherwise, you just have a Frankenstein product.
text_ko: 프로토타이핑(prototyping)하고 직접 만들어 보면서 '무엇을 만들고 싶은지' 확인하지 않는다면, 그건 잘못하고 있는 거예요. 그래서 그 중심엔 편집적 판단(editorial)과 취향 결정(taste-making)이 더 중요해져요. 안 그러면 결국 여기저기 붙여 놓은 프랑켄슈타인 같은 제품이 될 뿐이에요.
text_zh: 如果你不去做原型、不去实际搭建来看看自己到底想做什么，我觉得这个方向就错了。这时候更需要有人把关产品方向和品味，不然最后出来的就是个四不像的产品。
text_es: Si no estás haciendo prototipos y construyendo para ver qué es lo que realmente quieres crear, creo que lo estás haciendo mal. Se vuelve aún más importante tener ese criterio editorial y ese buen gusto en el centro de todo, porque si no, terminas con un producto Frankenstein.
context: Lenny asks how the future of product development will be different from today. Aparna emphasizes that modern product development requires immediate prototyping rather than just writing specifications. She argues that the prompt is becoming the new PRD (Product Requirements Document) and that teams should demonstrate ideas through working prototypes. However, she warns that while AI makes it easier to generate ideas and prototypes, it also raises the bar for quality and requires strong editorial judgment to avoid creating disjointed products.
vocabulary_highlights: doing it wrong, editorial and taste-making, Frankenstein product

speaker: Aparna Chennapragada
text: Natural language interface. NLX is the new UX. Often I hear a product builders say, 'Oh, yeah. With AI, the model eats the products.' That doesn't mean it's not designed. You and I are having a conversation. It's a podcast. I'll have another conversation at Microsoft and that's a meeting. Conversations also have grammars. They have structures. They have UI elements. They're invisible.
text_ko: 자연어 인터페이스 (Natural language interface). NLX는 새로운 UX (user experience)이에요. 제품을 만드는 분들한테서 종종 "아, 그렇죠. AI가 들어오면 모델이 제품을 대체한다"라고 듣곤 해요. 하지만 그게 설계가 안 돼 있다는 뜻은 아니에요. 지금 우리 둘이 대화를 나누고 있어요. 이건 팟캐스트고, 제가 마이크로소프트에서 나눌 다른 대화는 회의예요. 대화에도 문법이 있고 구조가 있으며, UI 요소 (UI elements)가 있어요. 다만 눈에 보이지 않을 뿐이에요.
text_zh: 自然语言界面，NLX就是新的UX。我经常听到产品开发的人说，"哦对，有了AI，模型把产品都吃掉了。"但这不意味着就不用设计了。你看，咱俩现在在聊天，这是播客。我待会儿在微软还要开个会，那是会议。对话其实也有语法的，有结构，有UI元素，只是你看不见而已。
text_es: Interfaz de lenguaje natural. NLX es el nuevo UX. A menudo escucho a los que desarrollan productos decir: "Ah, sí. Con la IA, el modelo se come los productos." Pero eso no significa que no tenga diseño. Tú y yo estamos teniendo una conversación. Es un podcast. Luego tendré otra conversación en Microsoft y esa será una reunión. Las conversaciones también tienen sus reglas gramaticales. Tienen estructuras. Tienen elementos de interfaz. Son invisibles.
context: Lenny asks about the acronym NLX that Aparna had mentioned. She explains that NLX stands for Natural Language Interface and represents a fundamental shift in how users interact with products. Aparna argues that just because AI interactions feel conversational doesn't mean they're undesigned - conversations have their own invisible structures, grammars, and UI elements that need to be carefully crafted. She's pushing back against the common belief that AI products design themselves.
vocabulary_highlights: the model eats the products, grammars, invisible UI elements

speaker: Aparna Chennapragada
text: I feel like a lot of the companies, including the tech companies, but certainly the enterprises that I talk to are in these two modes where one hand, this is the most compressed tech cycle that we've ever experienced. It's in the order of weeks and months versus years and decades. On the other hand, there's also humans and habits that... Productivity habits change. It's hard to change and change management through the company is also hard.
text_ko: 제가 만나는 많은 회사들, 특히 테크 회사들뿐 아니라 엔터프라이즈들도 두 가지 모드에 있는 것 같아요. 한편으로는 지금이 우리가 경험한 것 중 가장 압축된 기술 주기(tech cycle)라서 변화가 몇 주, 몇 달 단위로 일어나고 예전처럼 몇 년·몇십 년 단위가 아니에요. 다른 한편으로는 사람들과 습관이 있어서요... 생산성 습관(productivity habits)은 쉽게 바뀌지 않고 조직 전체의 변화 관리(change management)도 쉽지 않아요.
text_zh: 我感觉很多公司，包括科技公司，特别是我接触的那些企业，现在都面临两个矛盾的情况。一方面，这是我们经历过的最紧凑的技术周期(tech cycle)，以前是按年、按十年来算的，现在是按周、按月来算。另一方面呢，人的习惯很难改变，特别是工作习惯。想要提高生产力，改变习惯本来就不容易，再加上整个公司的变革管理(change management)也很难推进。
text_es: Me parece que muchas de las empresas con las que hablo, incluyendo las de tecnología, pero especialmente las grandes corporaciones, están como en estos dos modos: por un lado, este es el ciclo tecnológico más acelerado que hemos vivido jamás. Estamos hablando de semanas y meses en lugar de años y décadas. Pero por otro lado, también están los humanos y los hábitos... Los hábitos de productividad cambian. Es difícil cambiar y la gestión del cambio (change management) en toda la empresa también es complicada.
context: Lenny asks what's most different about working at Microsoft compared to consumer internet companies. Aparna uses the metaphor of Jean-Claude Van Damme doing splits between two moving trucks to describe the challenge enterprises face. She explains that companies must balance two conflicting pressures: the incredibly fast pace of AI development happening in weeks and months, versus the slow pace of human behavior change and organizational change management that companies need for successful adoption.
vocabulary_highlights: compressed tech cycle, change management through the company

speaker: Aparna Chennapragada
text: When I think about agents, I think about these three things. So one, it's autonomy like being... And it's a spectrum, it's not a zero-one, it's how do I actually delegate things that it can do. Second, I think of as complexity. It's not a one-shot, 'Hey, summarize this document, generate this image, but it's build me this prototype or help me knock this meeting out of the park.' And then the third one I think of is it's a much more natural interaction.
text_ko: 에이전트(agent)에 대해 생각하면 세 가지가 먼저 떠올라요. 첫째는 자율성(autonomy)인데, 완전한 0·1 문제가 아니라 스펙트럼(spectrum)처럼 어느 정도까지 일을 맡길 수 있느냐의 문제예요. 둘째는 복잡성인데, '이 문서 요약해'나 '이미지 만들어' 같은 원샷(one-shot) 작업이 아니라 '이 프로토타입(prototype)을 만들어줘'라든지 '이 회의를 완벽하게 해내도록 도와줘'처럼 더 복잡한 과제를 수행하는 능력이에요. 셋째는 훨씬 더 자연스러운 상호작용(natural interaction)이에요.
text_zh: 我一想到智能代理(agents)，就会想到三个方面。第一个是自主性，就是说...这是个程度问题，不是非黑即白，而是我能把哪些事儿真正放心交给它去做。第二个我觉得是复杂性。不是那种一次性的简单任务，比如"帮我总结一下这个文档"或者"生成个图片"，而是"帮我搭个原型"或者"帮我把这个会议搞定"这种。第三个就是交互方式更自然了。
text_es: Cuando pienso en agentes, pienso en estas tres cosas. Primero, está la autonomía, como ser... Y es un espectro, no es algo de cero o uno, sino más bien cómo le puedo delegar cosas que realmente puede hacer. Segundo, pienso en la complejidad. No es algo de una sola vez como "Oye, resume este documento, genera esta imagen", sino más bien "construyeme este prototipo" o "ayúdame a que esta reunión sea un éxito total". Y tercero, pienso que es una interacción mucho más natural.
context: Lenny asks Aparna to define what agents actually are, since the term is used everywhere but often unclear. Aparna provides her framework for understanding AI agents through three key characteristics. She emphasizes that agents represent an evolution from simple AI assistance to more sophisticated tools that can handle complex, multi-step tasks independently while maintaining natural communication with users. This is her practical product-building perspective on what distinguishes agents from regular AI tools.
vocabulary_highlights: one-shot, knock this meeting out of the park, natural interaction

speaker: Aparna Chennapragada
text: I've repeatedly learned that when you're doing something new, zero-to-one, the temptation is to kind of think about... It's like that South Park episode. So I've always said to my teams solve before scale. So what that does mean is there's a different posture and different mode when you're trying to solve a problem versus scaling something that's either post-product market fit or even at least in roughly in the ballpark.
text_ko: 새로운 걸 할 때, 제로에서 원(Zero-to-One)으로 가는 과정에서 항상 느끼는 건, 뭔가를 해결하기 전에 먼저 확장(scale)하려는 유혹이 있다는 거예요. 마치 '사우스 파크(South Park)' 에피소드처럼요. 그래서 저는 항상 제 팀에게 문제를 해결한 다음에 확장하라고 말해요. 이게 의미하는 건, 문제를 해결할 때와 제품 시장 적합성(product market fit) 이후에 확장할 때는 자세와 접근 방식이 다르다는 거예요.
text_zh: 我反复发现，当你在做全新的事情，从零到一(zero-to-one)的时候，你会忍不住想...就像那集《南方公园》一样。所以我一直跟我的团队说，先解决问题，再考虑规模化(scale)。这意思就是说，你解决问题的时候和扩大规模的时候，心态和做法是完全不一样的——后者要么是已经找到了产品市场契合点(product market fit)，要么至少差不多在那个范围内了。
text_es: He aprendido una y otra vez que cuando estás haciendo algo completamente nuevo, de cero a uno (zero-to-one), la tentación es como pensar... Es como ese episodio de South Park. Por eso siempre le digo a mis equipos: resuelvan antes de escalar (solve before scale). Lo que esto significa es que hay una mentalidad y un enfoque completamente distinto cuando estás tratando de resolver un problema versus escalar algo que ya tiene product-market fit o que por lo menos anda más o menos en la dirección correcta.
context: Lenny asks about counterintuitive lessons Aparna has learned about building products that go against common startup wisdom. She references the South Park 'underpants gnomes' episode (step 1: collect underpants, step 2: ?, step 3: profit) to illustrate how startups often jump to scaling before actually solving the core problem. Her key insight is that teams need to be comfortable with chaos and wide pivots during the solve phase, rather than prematurely optimizing for growth metrics.
vocabulary_highlights: zero-to-one, solve before scale, different posture and different mode, in the ballpark

speaker: April Dunford
text: 40 to 60% of B2B purchase processes end in no decision. If you scratch on that data, the majority of those aren't saying, "Well, I'm not making a decision to buy something new because the old thing we were doing is better." That's not true at all. In fact, the majority of those is they couldn't figure out how to make a choice confidently.
text_ko: 기업 간 거래(B2B) 구매 과정의 40~60%는 결국 결정을 내리지 못한 채 끝나요. 그 수치를 조금만 파고들어 보면, 그중 대부분이 '기존에 하던 게 더 좋아서 새로 사지 않는다'고 말하는 게 아니에요. 전혀 그렇지 않아요. 사실 대부분은 어떻게 자신 있게 선택을 내릴지 몰라서 결정을 못 내리는 경우예요.
text_zh: B2B采购流程中，有40%到60%最后都没下决定。你仔细琢磨这个数据就会发现，大部分情况下他们并不是在说"我不买新东西是因为我们原来那套更好用"——完全不是这么回事。实际上，大部分人是因为拿不准该怎么选，没信心做决定。
text_es: Entre el 40 y 60% de los procesos de compra B2B terminan sin que se tome ninguna decisión. Si te pones a analizar esos datos, la mayoría de esas empresas no están diciendo "No voy a comprar algo nuevo porque lo que teníamos antes funcionaba mejor." Para nada. En realidad, la mayoría simplemente no logró encontrar la manera de tomar una decisión con confianza.
context: Lenny asks April about the challenges B2B buyers face when making purchasing decisions. April shares a striking statistic that reveals a major problem in B2B sales: nearly half of all purchase processes don't result in any decision at all. She explains that buyers aren't rejecting new solutions because they prefer their current approach - instead, they're paralyzed by uncertainty and can't confidently choose between options, leading them to postpone decisions entirely.
vocabulary_highlights: scratch on that data, on the hook to make the decision

speaker: April Dunford
text: What B2B software buyers want in a sales interaction is perspectives on the market and help weighing their options. And we don't do that. We're just like, "Here's our stuff. You figure it out, it's up to you. You figure it out." And so as a result, what we get are these buyers come in, they're overwhelmed with all this information.
text_ko: B2B 소프트웨어 구매자(B2B software buyers)는 영업 상호작용(sales interaction)에서 시장에 대한 관점과 여러 선택지를 비교해 볼 수 있게 도와주길 원해요. 근데 우리는 그걸 안 해요. 그냥 “여기 우리 제품이에요. 알아서 하세요, 너희가 판단하세요.” 이렇게 끝내버리죠. 그래서 결국 구매자들은 온갖 정보에 압도돼 버려요.
text_zh: B2B软件采购方在销售过程中真正想要的是对市场的洞察，还有帮他们权衡各种选择。但我们根本没有做到这一点。我们就是那种"喏，这就是我们的产品，你自己琢磨吧，反正随你。你自己想办法。"结果呢，客户进来的时候被这么多信息搞得晕头转向。
text_es: Lo que realmente buscan los compradores de software B2B en una interacción de ventas son perspectivas del mercado y ayuda para evaluar sus opciones. Y nosotros no hacemos eso. Simplemente decimos: "Aquí tienes nuestro producto. Tú te las arreglas, es cosa tuya. Tú figúrate cómo hacerle." Y entonces lo que pasa es que estos compradores llegan y están abrumados con toda esta información.
context: April discusses what B2B software buyers actually need from sales interactions versus what they typically receive. She explains that research shows buyers want guidance on understanding the entire market landscape and help evaluating their options, but most vendors simply showcase their product features without providing this broader context. This mismatch leaves buyers feeling overwhelmed rather than educated, making them less likely to make a purchase decision.
vocabulary_highlights: weighing their options, you figure it out

speaker: April Dunford
text: So what they did was they just went to their boss and said, "You know what? Now's not a good time. Let's not do it now. Let's do it next year. Let's just delay it," because that is the safe risk-free thing for that person who's on the hook to make the decision to do.
text_ko: 그래서 그들이 한 건, 그냥 상사한테 가서 "지금은 좋은 시기가 아니에요. 지금은 안 하는 게 좋겠어요. 내년에 하죠. 그냥 미루죠."라고 말한 거예요. 결정을 내려야 하는 사람 입장에서는 그게 가장 안전하고 위험 부담이 없는 선택이었거든요.
text_zh: 所以他们就直接找老板说："你看啊，现在时机不太好，咱们先别搞了，明年再说吧，先缓缓。" 因为对于那个要拍板决定的人来说，这样做最稳妥，不用承担什么风险。
text_es: Entonces lo que hicieron fue ir directo con su jefe y decirle: "¿Sabes qué? Ahora no es buen momento. No lo hagamos ahorita. Mejor lo dejamos para el año que viene. Vamos a posponerlo," porque esa es la opción más segura y sin riesgo para la persona que tiene que cargar con la responsabilidad de tomar esa decisión.
context: April explains why so many B2B purchase processes end without a decision. When buyers can't figure out how to make a choice confidently between different software options, they often choose the safest path: delaying the decision entirely. She describes how overwhelmed buyers will tell their supervisors it's not the right time to purchase, essentially kicking the can down the road because making no decision feels less risky than potentially making the wrong choice.
vocabulary_highlights: on the hook to make the decision, safe risk-free thing

speaker: April Dunford
text: Once you get into that mindset, I think then you look at the situation a lot different. I think we've seen the statistics on this that says the buyer is 80% of the way through their buying journey by the time they talk to your sales rep. Yeah, maybe, but they might be 80% of the way to saying, "Nope, I'm not buying nothing."
text_ko: 그런 마인드셋(mindset)을 갖게 되면 상황을 훨씬 다르게 보게 돼요. 통계를 보면 구매자가 영업 담당자(sales rep)와 이야기하기 전까지 구매 여정(buying journey)의 80%를 이미 밟는다고 하더라고요. 그럴 수도 있죠. 근데 그 80%가 이미 "아니요, 안 살래"로 가는 과정일 수도 있다는 거예요.
text_zh: 一旦你转变了这种思维方式，我觉得你看问题的角度就完全不一样了。我们看到过相关数据，说客户在跟你的销售聊之前，已经完成了80%的购买决策流程。没错，也许是这样，但他们也可能是在80%的路上走向"算了，我什么都不买"。
text_es: Una vez que adoptas esa mentalidad, creo que entonces ves la situación de manera muy diferente. Creo que hemos visto las estadísticas que dicen que el comprador ya va en un 80% de su proceso de compra cuando habla con tu vendedor. Sí, puede ser, pero también puede ser que vaya en un 80% hacia decir "No, de esto no compro nada."
context: April challenges a common assumption in sales about buyer behavior. While conventional wisdom suggests buyers are nearly ready to purchase by the time they engage with sales teams, April points out this statistic might be misleading. She argues that buyers may indeed be far along in their journey - but toward deciding not to buy anything at all, rather than being close to making a purchase. This reframes how sales teams should approach these interactions.
vocabulary_highlights: get into that mindset, I'm not buying nothing

speaker: April Dunford
text: If a customer is indecisive, throwing FOMO into the mix makes it worse. So they're less likely to close the deal if you throw that in. And the idea is that they're already stressed out and you're just putting more stress on them by pressuring them, by saying, "Oh, this is happening, bad things are going to..." You're like, "Bad things will happen if I do something, bad things happen if I don't do something, what do I do?"
text_ko: 고객이 망설이고 있을 때 여기에 FOMO(놓칠까 봐 불안함)를 섞으면 상황이 오히려 더 안 좋아져요. 그렇게 하면 거래 성사 가능성도 낮아져요. 애초에 고객이 이미 스트레스를 받고 있는데 압박해서 “지금 이러이러한 일이 생기고 있어서 안 좋을 거예요…”라고 하면 스트레스를 더하는 셈이에요. 결국 “이렇게 하면 나쁜 일이 생기고, 안 하면 또 나쁜 일이 생기면 도대체 어떡하라는 거야?” 같은 상태가 돼 버려요.
text_zh: 如果客户本来就犹豫不决，你再搞什么错失恐惧(FOMO)那一套，只会让情况更糟。这样一来他们成交的可能性反而更小。道理很简单，他们本来就已经很焦虑了，你还在那儿给他们施压，说什么"哎呀，要出什么事了，不好的事情会..."结果客户就想："我做了会出事，不做也会出事，那我到底该怎么办？"
text_es: Si un cliente ya está indeciso, meterle el miedo de perderse algo (FOMO) lo empeora todo. Así que es menos probable que cierre el trato si le echas esa presión encima. La cosa es que ya están estresados y tú nomás les estás agregando más estrés al presionarlos, diciéndoles "Ay, esto está pasando, van a pasar cosas malas si..." Y ellos quedan como "Van a pasar cosas malas si hago algo, van a pasar cosas malas si no hago nada, ¿entonces qué hago?"
context: April shares insights from Matt Dixon's research on 2.5 million sales calls, revealing a counterintuitive finding about fear-based selling tactics. When discussing how to handle indecisive customers, she explains that using FOMO (fear of missing out) actually backfires with uncertain buyers. Rather than motivating them to act, adding pressure through fear tactics increases their stress levels and makes them more likely to avoid making any decision at all, as they become paralyzed by potential negative outcomes regardless of their choice.
vocabulary_highlights: throwing FOMO into the mix, close the deal

speaker: April Dunford
text: So he's just the best. And so one of the things I think of is normally when we come at this we're like, "Well, how can we convince the customer that we do the job that they need to have done?" And obviously we need to do that, but there is this secondary job that the champion of the deal is, and that's how do I make a decision without getting fired?
text_ko: 그러니까 그는 정말 최고예요. 그리고 제가 생각하는 것 중 하나는, 보통 우리가 이걸 다룰 때는 "어떻게 고객을 설득해서 우리가 필요한 일을 해낼 수 있다고 믿게 만들까?"라고 해요. 그건 당연히 필요한 일이지만, 딜 챔피언(champion of the deal)에게는 또 다른 역할이 있어요. 바로 "어떻게 해고당하지 않고 결정을 내릴 수 있을까?"예요.
text_zh: 所以他真的是最棒的。我觉得通常我们处理这种情况的时候，都会想"怎么让客户相信我们能搞定他们需要的事？"这个肯定得做，但是还有一个层面就是那个项目负责人(champion)他自己的考虑——我怎么做决定才不会被炒鱿鱼？
text_es: Entonces él es simplemente el mejor. Y una de las cosas en las que pienso es que normalmente cuando abordamos esto decimos: "Bueno, ¿cómo podemos convencer al cliente de que hacemos el trabajo que necesita?" Y obviamente tenemos que hacer eso, pero hay un trabajo secundario que tiene el champion del negocio, y es: ¿cómo tomo una decisión sin que me corran?
context: April references a conversation with Bob Moesta about Jobs To Be Done theory and reveals a crucial insight about B2B sales. She explains that while salespeople focus on convincing customers their product can solve the business problem, there's an equally important but often overlooked concern: the personal risk faced by the decision-maker. The person championing the purchase has a secondary job - protecting their own career by making a safe decision that won't result in negative consequences for them personally.
vocabulary_highlights: champion of the deal, getting fired

speaker: April Dunford
text: If we're really smart, we already know because we've done lots of deals. So if we're being a good partner in this, sometimes even in the very first meeting in that spot where we're talking about objectives, we're going to say, "Hey, look, IT is going to come in and they're going to be worried about this, this, and this, and don't worry, we got you."
text_ko: 우리가 정말 똑똑하면 이미 알고 있어요. 딜(deal)을 많이 해봤으니까요. 그래서 좋은 파트너가 되려면, 때로는 첫 미팅에서 목표(objectives)에 대해 이야기할 때 바로 이렇게 말해요. "자, 보세요. IT(IT)팀이 들어와서 이거, 저거, 또 이거를 걱정할 거예요. 근데 걱정 마세요, 우리가 다 챙겨드릴게요."
text_zh: 如果我们真的有经验，其实心里早就有数了，因为我们做过很多单子。所以如果我们真的想做个靠谱的合作伙伴，有时候甚至在第一次见面聊目标的时候，我们就会说："你看，IT部门肯定会来插一脚，他们会担心这个那个的，但是别担心，我们都能搞定。"
text_es: Si de verdad sabemos lo que hacemos, ya tenemos experiencia porque hemos cerrado un montón de tratos.
