Entonces, si somos buenos socios en esto, a veces hasta en la primera junta cuando estamos hablando de objetivos, vamos a decir: "Oye, mira, va a llegar IT y se van a preocupar por esto, esto y esto, pero tranquilo, nosotros te cubrimos."
context: April explains how experienced sales teams can proactively address objections before they arise in complex B2B deals. She discusses the multi-stakeholder nature of B2B purchases, where IT departments, end users, and other groups will each have different concerns. Rather than waiting for objections to surface, savvy salespeople anticipate these concerns based on previous deals and address them early in the process, demonstrating expertise while removing potential roadblocks for their champion.
vocabulary_highlights: being a good partner, we got you

speaker: April Dunford
text: So in the work I do, and even back when I was a VP marketing, if we're going to fix this thing, we can't just have the marketing department or just the product managers sit down and cook up new positioning and then heave it over the wall to everybody else, it actually needs to be a group effort. It's a team sport.
text_ko: 제가 하는 일에서도, 그리고 마케팅 부사장(VP Marketing)이었을 때도 그랬어요. 이걸 고치려면 마케팅 부서나 제품 매니저들만 따로 앉아서 새로운 포지셔닝(positioning)을 짜 놓고 다른 사람들에게 떠넘기는 식으로는 안 돼요. 실제로는 모두가 함께 힘을 합쳐야 해요. 팀 스포츠(team sport)예요.
text_zh: 所以在我现在做的工作中，包括我之前当营销副总的时候，如果我们要解决这个问题，不能只是营销部门或者产品经理坐下来自己琢磨新的定位(positioning)，然后直接丢给其他人，这事儿必须得大家一起来。这是个团队合作的活儿。
text_es: Entonces en el trabajo que hago, e incluso cuando era VP de marketing, si vamos a arreglar esto, no podemos simplemente que el departamento de marketing o solo los product managers se sienten a cocinar un nuevo posicionamiento y después se lo aviente a todos los demás por encima del muro, en realidad tiene que ser un esfuerzo de grupo. Es un deporte de equipo.
context: Lenny asks about who should care about positioning beyond just founders. April explains that weak positioning often comes from misalignment across different departments - where founders, marketing, sales, and product teams all have slightly different understandings of the company's positioning. She emphasizes that positioning cannot be developed in isolation by one department and then imposed on others.
vocabulary_highlights: cook up, heave it over the wall, team sport

speaker: April Dunford
text: When it's working really well, it feels like magic and really great positioning feels obvious. You pitch it to people and they're like, 'Well, of course that's it. What else could it be?' One of my favorite companies, this is a company I worked with a little bit a couple of years ago is Postman.
text_ko: 정말 잘 작동할 때는 마법 같아요. 훌륭한 포지셔닝(positioning)은 너무 당연해 보이죠. 사람들한테 그걸 피치(pitch)하면 “당연히 그거지, 다른 게 뭐가 있겠어?”라고 반응해요. 제가 좋아하는 회사 중 하나고, 몇 년 전에 잠깐 같이 일한 회사가 Postman이에요.
text_zh: 当它运作得特别好的时候，感觉就像变魔术一样，真正好的定位(positioning)就是让人觉得理所当然。你跟别人一说，他们马上就会想"对啊，就应该是这样啊，不然还能是什么呢？" 我特别喜欢的一家公司——几年前我跟他们合作过一段时间——就是Postman。
text_es: Cuando funciona muy bien, se siente como magia y un posicionamiento realmente bueno parece obvio. Se lo presentas a la gente y te dicen: "Pues claro, eso es. ¿Qué otra cosa podría ser?" Una de mis empresas favoritas, una compañía con la que trabajé un poco hace un par de años, es Postman.
context: Lenny asks what it looks like when you've nailed positioning and are in a good place with it. April explains that excellent positioning should feel natural and self-evident to customers. She uses Postman as an example - they have an API platform for building and using APIs, which sounds simple and obvious now, but wasn't always described that clearly.
vocabulary_highlights: feels like magic, feels obvious

speaker: April Dunford
text: But particularly, I've worked a lot with companies doing deep AI stuff, deep, deep digital analytics and deep data stuff and you can't tell from looking at the website, whether it's working or not. The true test of whether the positioning's working or not is, if I'm sitting across from a qualified prospect and I tell the story, does the prospect get excited and want to buy something? That's the real test of it.
text_ko: 특히 저는 딥 AI(Deep AI), 정말 심도 깊은 디지털 애널리틱스(digital analytics)나 딥 데이터(deep data) 관련 일을 하는 회사들과 많이 일해 왔어요. 그런데 웹사이트만 보고는 그게 실제로 잘 작동하는지 알 수가 없어요. 포지셔닝(positioning)이 잘 먹히는지의 진짜 시험은, 자격을 갖춘 잠재고객(qualified prospect)과 마주 앉아 스토리를 들려줬을 때 그 사람이 흥분해서 구매하고 싶어 하느냐는 거예요. 그게 진짜 시험이에요.
text_zh: 特别是我跟很多做深度AI、深度数字分析和深度数据处理的公司合作过，光看网站你根本看不出来定位到底行不行。真正检验定位是否有效的标准是什么呢？就是当我坐在一个合格的潜在客户面前，给他讲我们的故事时，这个客户会不会激动起来，会不会想要买我们的东西？这才是真正的检验标准。
text_es: Pero especialmente, he trabajado mucho with empresas que hacen cosas muy profundas de IA, análisis digitales súper complejos y temas de big data muy avanzados, y no puedes saber si está funcionando solo viendo la página web. La verdadera prueba de si el posicionamiento está funcionando es: si estoy sentado frente a un prospecto calificado y le cuento la historia, ¿se emociona el prospecto y quiere comprar algo? Esa es la prueba real.
context: Lenny asks for examples of good positioning statements and well-positioned companies. April explains that B2B tech positioning cannot be judged by external observers - what matters is whether it resonates with the actual target buyers. She points out that deeply technical products may seem unclear to outsiders but should be crystal clear to qualified prospects.
vocabulary_highlights: deep AI stuff, deep, deep digital analytics, qualified prospect

speaker: April Dunford
text: So in B2B, we have two sets of competitors. We have status quo, which is whatever the company is doing to attempt to solve the problem right now, even if it's crappy and not great. And then there's if the company does decide they're going to buy something different, they usually make a short list, so it's whoever else lands on the short list.
text_ko: 기업 간 거래(B2B)에서는 경쟁자가 두 종류예요. 하나는 현상 유지(status quo)인데, 지금 회사가 문제를 해결하려고 하고 있는 모든 방식이에요 — 설령 엉망이고 별로여도요. 그리고 회사가 다른 걸 사기로 결정하면 보통 숏리스트(short list)를 만들어요. 그래서 결국 숏리스트에 오른 다른 업체들이 경쟁자가 되는 거예요.
text_zh: 所以在B2B里面，我们面对两种竞争对手。第一种是现状，就是客户公司现在用来解决问题的方法，哪怕这个方法很烂、效果不好。第二种是如果公司真的决定要买新的解决方案，他们通常会列个候选名单，那就是跟我们一起进入候选名单的那些竞争对手。
text_es: Entonces en B2B, tenemos dos tipos de competencia. Está el status quo, que es lo que sea que esté haciendo la empresa ahora mismo para tratar de resolver el problema, aunque sea malo y no funcione bien. Y después está cuando la empresa sí decide que va a comprar algo diferente, que normalmente hacen una lista corta, entonces es quien sea que también quede en esa lista corta.
context: Lenny asks about the first step in positioning work. April explains her methodology starts with understanding competitive alternatives - what you need to beat to win deals. She clarifies that B2B companies face two types of competition: the current status quo (existing solutions, even poor ones) and other vendors that make it onto the customer's shortlist when they decide to buy something new.
vocabulary_highlights: status quo, short list, lands on the short list

speaker: April Dunford
text: Most folks will discount the status quo, but they shouldn't because in B2B we lose about 40% of our deals to quote-unquote, 'no decision,' which actually means we lost to the spreadsheet, we lost to pen and paper, we lost to interns. And if we're not positioning well against that, we're never going to get the customer to come off of that.
text_ko: 대부분 사람들은 현상 유지(status quo)를 가볍게 보는데, 그럴 일이 아니에요. B2B(기업 간 거래)에서는 거래의 약 40%를 소위 '결정 없음'(no decision)에 잃거든요. 사실 그건 스프레드시트(spreadsheet), 펜과 종이(pen and paper), 인턴(interns)에게 진 거예요. 그리고 그걸 잘 공략하지 않으면 고객을 거기서 벗어나게 만들 수가 없어요.
text_zh: 大多数人都不把现状当回事，但其实不应该这样，因为在B2B里面，我们大概有40%的单子都败给了所谓的"不做决定"，说白了就是败给了Excel表格，败给了纸笔记录，败给了实习生在用的那些老办法。如果我们不好好地跟这些东西做对比，突出我们的优势，客户永远不会放弃他们现在的做法。
text_es: La mayoría de la gente subestima el status quo, pero no deberían hacerlo porque en B2B perdemos como el 40% de nuestras ventas por lo que llaman "no hay decisión", que en realidad significa que perdimos contra la hoja de cálculo, perdimos contra el lápiz y papel, perdimos contra los becarios. Y si no nos posicionamos bien contra eso, nunca vamos a lograr que el cliente se mueva de ahí.
context: April continues explaining competitive alternatives in positioning work. She emphasizes that companies often underestimate the status quo as competition, but this is a major mistake. In B2B sales, a significant portion of deals are lost not to competitors, but to customers deciding to stick with their current solution, no matter how inadequate it might seem.
vocabulary_highlights: discount the status quo, quote-unquote, come off of that

speaker: April Dunford
text: And so we have to be able to give customers that when they get on the sales call with us. The best thing we could do is say, 'Look, buddy, there's lots of CRMs out there, and let me tell you how this market shakes out. These ones are really good for big enterprises. These ones are really good, if you got this. These ones are really good, if you got this. But look, if you're this, this and this, you really need these four things and we got that and that's why you should pick us.'
text_ko: 그래서 고객이 우리와 영업 상담(sales call)을 할 때 그걸 제공할 수 있어야 해요. 가장 좋은 방법은 솔직히 말해서, "보세요, 고객관계관리 시스템(CRM)이 정말 많고 이 시장이 어떻게 정리되는지 제가 설명드릴게요. 어떤 것들은 대기업에 잘 맞고, 어떤 것들은 이런 경우에, 또 어떤 것들은 저런 경우에 더 좋아요. 그런데 만약 고객님이 이런 조건이라면 진짜로 필요한 건 이 네 가지이고, 그걸 저희가 모두 갖추고 있으니 그래서 저희를 선택하셔야 해요."라고 말하는 거예요.
text_zh: 所以我们在跟客户电话销售的时候，必须能够给他们这样的体验。我们能做的最好的事情就是说："兄弟，市面上CRM系统多得是，我来跟你说说这个市场是怎么回事。这些产品特别适合大企业。这些呢，如果你有这种情况的话，特别好用。那些呢，如果你是那种情况，也很不错。但是你看，如果你是这样这样这样的情况，你真正需要的就是这四个功能，而我们正好有，这就是为什么你应该选我们。"
text_es: Y entonces tenemos que poder darles eso a los clientes cuando se suben a la llamada de ventas con nosotros. Lo mejor que podríamos hacer es decirles: 'Mira, amigo, hay un montón de CRMs por ahí, y déjame contarte cómo está el panorama de este mercado. Estos son buenísimos para empresas grandes. Estos otros están padrísimos si tienes esto. Estos funcionan de maravilla si tienes esto otro. Pero oye, si tú eres así, así y así, realmente necesitas estas cuatro cosas y nosotros las tenemos, y por eso nos deberías elegir.'
context: April describes the B2B buying process where a decision-maker assigns someone (like John) to research and recommend a solution. She explains that this person needs to justify their choice to their boss and cannot just pick randomly. The best positioning helps customers understand how the market is segmented and why your solution is specifically right for their situation.
vocabulary_highlights: how this market shakes out
topics: Product Management, Growth & Marketing, Strategy & Planning

speaker: April Dunford
text: A better way I think is we know internally that it's the tuna fishing net. That's why we built it. That's what it is, but let's just at the beginning, let's put it out there and keep it a little loose and we say, 'It's a net for fish, big fish, all kinds of big fish, any kind of big fish. And then let's just see, let's let the fishermen try it out. Let's see what they pull up.'
text_ko: 제 생각엔 더 좋은 방법은, 우리 내부적으로는 이게 참치잡이 그물(tuna fishing net)인 걸 이미 알고 있다는 거예요. 그래서 만든 거고요. 본질적으로 그게 맞아요. 근데 처음에는 그냥 밖에 내놓고 조금 느슨하게 시작해요. ‘물고기 잡는 그물이에요. 큰 물고기용이에요, 모든 종류의 큰 물고기—어떤 큰 물고기든요.’ 이렇게 말해두고 어부들한테 한번 써보게 해보고, 뭐가 올라오는지 지켜보자는 거예요.
text_zh: 我觉得更好的做法是这样的：我们内部心里清楚，这就是专门用来捕金枪鱼的网，我们就是为这个目的造的。但是刚开始的时候，我们对外可以说得宽泛一点，就说"这是捕大鱼用的网，什么大鱼都能捕，各种各样的大鱼都行。"然后我们就看看情况，让渔民们试试看，看他们能捞上来什么。
text_es: Creo que una mejor manera es que nosotros sabemos internamente que es una red para pescar atún. Para eso la construimos. Eso es lo que es, pero al principio, vamos a presentarla de manera más abierta y decimos: 'Es una red para peces, peces grandes, todo tipo de peces grandes, cualquier tipo de pez grande.' Y luego vamos a ver, dejemos que los pescadores la prueben. A ver qué pescan.
context: April discusses positioning strategy for early-stage companies. She uses a fishing net analogy to explain that while you may have built your product for a specific use case (tuna fishing), it's better to keep positioning somewhat loose initially rather than being overly restrictive. This allows the market to show you unexpected use cases and customer segments that might be even better fits.
vocabulary_highlights: keep it a little loose, let's see what they pull up
topics: Product Management, Strategy & Planning, Starting a Company

speaker: Archie Abrams
text: When you have teams naturally break up the world into different funnel stages or different points in the journey, it gets very seductive to look at my part of the funnel and what's my conversion rate through that part of the funnel, right? And then the team starts to optimize for that conversion rate as their north star. But in practice, it's actually almost always easier to just make it harder to do the thing right before your step in the funnel to increase your conversion rate.
text_ko: 팀들이 자연스럽게 세상을 퍼널(funnel) 단계나 여정의 각 지점으로 나누다 보면, 자기 맡은 퍼널 구간만 보고 그 구간의 전환율(conversion rate)만 들여다보게 되는 유혹에 빠져요. 그래서 팀은 그 전환율을 노스스타(north star)처럼 삼아 최적화하려고 하죠. 그런데 실제로는 전환율을 올리려면 자기 단계 바로 전 단계에서 그 행동을 더 어렵게 만들어(진입 장벽을 높여) 거기서 빠져나가게 하는 편이 훨씬 쉬운 경우가 거의 대부분이에요.
text_zh: 当团队很自然地把整个流程分解成不同的漏斗阶段(funnel stages)或者客户旅程的不同节点时，就特别容易陷入这样的思维陷阱：只盯着自己负责的那部分漏斗，关注通过自己这一环的转化率怎么样，对吧？然后团队就开始把提高这个转化率当成自己的北极星(north star)来优化。但实际操作中，几乎总是有一个更简单的套路——就是在你负责的环节前面那一步设置更高的门槛，这样你的转化率自然就上去了。
text_es: Cuando los equipos dividen naturalmente el mundo en diferentes etapas del embudo (funnel) o distintos puntos del proceso, se vuelve muy tentador enfocarse solo en mi parte del embudo y preguntar "¿cuál es mi tasa de conversión en esta etapa?", ¿no? Y entonces el equipo empieza a optimizar esa tasa de conversión como si fuera su estrella polar (north star). Pero en la práctica, casi siempre resulta más fácil simplemente hacer más difícil el paso justo antes de tu etapa del embudo para aumentar tu tasa de conversión.
context: Lenny asks about growth metrics and team incentives at Shopify. Archie explains a common problem where teams focus on conversion rates for their specific part of the customer funnel. He warns that when teams optimize for local conversion rates as their primary goal, they often inadvertently make it harder for users to reach their stage in the first place, which artificially inflates their conversion numbers but hurts overall business performance.
vocabulary_highlights: seductive, north star, conversion rate

speaker: Archie Abrams
text: Most businesses do ultimately fail. And so the way we look at it is can we lower the barriers to getting started and get as many people in the door trying their hand at entrepreneurship? If we do that, again, many of those businesses, many of those folks will maybe on their first attempt not be as successful, but we're going to have a set of merchants who go on to become extremely big businesses, the Allbirds of the world, FIGS, etc.
text_ko: 대부분의 사업은 결국 실패하기 마련이에요. 그래서 저희는 시작 장벽을 낮춰서 가능한 한 많은 분들이 창업에 도전해 보게 하는 게 중요하다고 봐요. 그렇게 하면 물론 처음엔 많은 사업과 많은 분들이 성공하지 못할 수도 있지만, 그중 일부는 나중에 Allbirds나 FIGS처럼 엄청나게 성장하는 사업체가 될 거예요.
text_zh: 大部分生意最终都是会失败的。所以我们的想法就是，能不能把创业的门槛降低一点，让更多人进来试试水，尝试一下创业？如果我们能做到这点，虽然说这些生意、这些创业者里面很多人第一次可能不会那么成功，但我们肯定会有一批商家最后做成非常大的企业，像Allbirds、FIGS这种级别的公司。
text_es: La mayoría de los negocios al final fracasan. Entonces, nosotros lo vemos así: ¿podemos bajar las barreras para empezar y lograr que entre la mayor cantidad de gente posible a probar suerte con el emprendimiento? Si hacemos eso, claro, muchos de esos negocios, muchas de esas personas tal vez en su primer intento no van a tener tanto éxito, pero vamos a tener un grupo de comerciantes que van a llegar a convertirse en empresas súper grandes, como los Allbirds del mundo, FIGS, y así.
context: Lenny asks why Shopify seems to optimize for churn rather than retention like most SaaS companies. Archie explains Shopify's unique philosophy around entrepreneurship and business failure. Unlike traditional SaaS companies that want to retain every customer, Shopify focuses on making it easy for people to start businesses, knowing that many will fail but the successful ones will generate massive value that makes the entire cohort profitable.
vocabulary_highlights: lower the barriers, trying their hand at, go on to become

speaker: Archie Abrams
text: I think there's probably two things that have been very common. And I would say in quite a few cases, you get a lift on a metric up front, a more short-term metric. Number of people who become a paying shopper, number of people who make their first sale in Shopify. And then you look a year later, and there's actually no incremental lift on GMV from that cohort.
text_ko: 아마 자주 나타나는 현상이 두 가지 정도 있는 것 같아요. 그리고 꽤 많은 경우에서, 초반에는 단기 지표(metric)가 올라가는 걸 보게 돼요. 예를 들어 유료 구매자 수(paying shopper)나 Shopify에서 첫 판매(first sale)를 한 사람이 늘어나고요. 그런데 1년쯤 지나서 보면, 그 코호트(cohort)에서는 총거래액(GMV)에 대한 실제 추가 상승이 전혀 없어요.
text_zh: 我觉得主要有两个很常见的情况。很多时候你会发现，前期的数据确实有提升，比如那些短期指标——付费用户数量啊，在Shopify上首次成交的用户数啊，这些都会涨。但是你一年后再看，这批用户在GMV上其实没有带来什么增量提升。
text_es: Creo que hay probablemente dos cosas que han sido muy comunes. Y diría que en bastantes casos, ves una mejora en una métrica al principio, una métrica más a corto plazo. El número de personas que se convierten en compradores de pago, el número de personas que hacen su primera venta en Shopify. Y después, cuando lo revisas un año más tarde, en realidad no hay ningún aumento incremental en el GMV de esa cohorte.
context: Lenny asks about Shopify's practice of running long-term holdout experiments to see if initial positive results hold up over time. Archie explains what they've learned from looking at experiments a year or more later. He describes how many experiments that show immediate positive impact on short-term metrics like conversions or first sales actually show no lasting effect on the business's core metric of GMV (Gross Merchandise Value) when measured over longer time periods.
vocabulary_highlights: lift on a metric, up front, incremental lift

speaker: Archie Abrams
text: If you think about in a business case, if I give you a little monetary boost and reduce that monetary friction, I can actually causally change your ability to become successful, because I've given you a little bit more time to try that idea a little bit longer. I've given you that opportunity to move your business over to Shopify. And so often in those types of experiments you see that you've basically unlocked a class of people who might've given up without reducing that monetary friction
text_ko: 비즈니스 케이스(business case) 관점에서 보면, 제가 약간의 금전적 지원(monetary boost)을 해주고 그 금전적 장벽(monetary friction)을 낮춰주면 사람들이 성공할 수 있는 가능성을 실제로 바꿀 수 있어요. 그게 아이디어를 조금 더 오래 시도해볼 시간과, 예를 들어 사업을 Shopify로 옮길 기회를 줬기 때문이에요. 그런 실험에서는 대개 금전적 장벽을 낮춰주지 않았다면 포기했을 사람들 집단을 활성화시켰다는 걸 보게 돼요.
text_zh: 你想想商业场景下，如果我给你一点资金上的帮助，降低一下资金门槛，其实就能直接影响到你成功的可能性，因为这样你就有更多时间去试验你的想法，有机会把生意迁移到Shopify上。这种实验经常能看到一个现象，就是你基本上释放了一批人的潜力，如果不降低资金门槛的话，他们可能早就放弃了
text_es: Si lo piensas desde el punto de vista del negocio, si te doy un pequeño empujón financiero y reduzco esa barrera económica, en realidad puedo cambiar directamente tu capacidad de tener éxito, porque te he dado un poco más de tiempo para probar esa idea por más tiempo. Te he dado esa oportunidad de migrar tu negocio a Shopify. Y muy seguido en ese tipo de experimentos ves que básicamente has desbloqueado a todo un grupo de personas que probablemente se habrían rendido sin reducir esa fricción monetaria (monetary friction).
context: Lenny asks for an example of experiments that revealed valuable merchant segments that weren't initially obvious. Archie explains how reducing 'monetary friction' - things like trial costs, subscription fees, or other financial barriers - can have unexpected long-term benefits. He describes how providing financial relief to new entrepreneurs can causally impact their success by giving them more time to develop their business ideas and build momentum before giving up.
vocabulary_highlights: monetary boost, causally change, unlocked a class of people

speaker: Archie Abrams
text: And because we focus on that long-term GMV, number of merchants who are successful, orienting every team to think about the total number of people, not the rate, but the total number of people who got to the end of their part of the journey is a very powerful way to incentivize people to do the right thing in terms of getting people set up versus do the, 'I'm going to constrict the funnel step right before me to make my local conversion rate look better,' which is the bane of my existence but something I see a lot of teams, implicitly or explicitly do when they get too focused on rates as a way to think about the world.
text_ko: 그리고 우리는 장기적인 GMV(총거래액)와 성공한 판매자 수에 집중하다 보니, 모든 팀이 비율이 아니라 '자기가 담당한 여정의 끝까지 도달한 사람의 총수'를 생각하도록 유도하는 게 정말 강력한 인센티브가 돼요. 그렇게 하면 사람들을 제대로 정착시키는 쪽으로 행동하게 되고, 자기 바로 앞 단계의 퍼널(funnel)을 조여서 로컬 전환율(conversion rate)만 좋아 보이게 하려는 식의 행동을 막을 수 있어요. 그건 제일 골칫거리예요. 그런데 팀들이 전환율 같은 비율에만 너무 집착하면 의도적이든 무의식적이든 그런 식으로 하는 경우를 많이 보게 돼요.
text_zh: 因为我们关注的是长期GMV和成功商家的数量，所以我们让每个团队都去想总人数——不是转化率，而是有多少人最终完成了他们那部分流程的总人数。这样激励大家做正确的事情，真正帮用户搞定设置，而不是搞那种"我要把我前面那个漏斗环节卡紧一点，好让我这边的局部转化率好看一些"的操作。这种做法简直是我最头疼的，但我看到很多团队，要么明着要么暗着都在这么干，就因为他们太盯着转化率这个指标了。
text_es: Y como nos enfocamos en ese GMV a largo plazo, en el número de comerciantes que tienen éxito, orientar a cada equipo para que piense en el número total de personas, no en la tasa, sino en el número total de personas que llegaron al final de su parte del proceso es una manera muy poderosa de incentivar a la gente a hacer lo correcto en términos de configurar bien a las personas, en lugar de hacer eso de "voy a estrechar el embudo (funnel) justo antes de mi paso para hacer que mi tasa de conversión local se vea mejor," que es mi pesadilla pero algo que veo que muchos equipos hacen, implícita o explícitamente, cuando se enfocan demasiado en las tasas como forma de ver el mundo.
context: Lenny asks about Shopify's focus on absolute numbers versus conversion rates as metrics. Archie explains how focusing teams on absolute numbers of successful users rather than conversion rates creates better incentives. He describes the problem where teams optimize local conversion rates by making it harder for people to reach their stage of the funnel, which hurts overall business performance. This misalignment of incentives is something he sees frequently across different organizations.
vocabulary_highlights: orienting every team, constrict the funnel, bane of my existence

speaker: Archie Abrams
text: And in practice, I talked about it's actually almost always easier to just make it harder to do the thing right before your step in the funnel to increase your conversion rate. If I make it harder to sign up, it's going to be very easy to increase sign up to activated rate, because I just have fewer people and the people who made it through our higher intent.
text_ko: 실제로는 전환율(conversion rate)을 올리려면 퍼널(funnel)에서 내 단계 바로 전에 그 행동을 일부러 더 어렵게 만드는 게 거의 항상 더 쉬운 방법이라고 말했어요. 예를 들어 가입(sign up)을 더 어렵게 하면 가입에서 활성화(activated rate)로 이어지는 비율을 올리는 건 훨씬 쉬워요. 통과한 사람이 줄고, 남은 사람들은 의도(intent)가 더 높은 사람들이니까요.
text_zh: 实际操作中我发现，要提高转化率(conversion rate)，最简单的方法其实是把漏斗(funnel)前一步的门槛设高一点。比如说，我把注册门槛提高了，那注册到激活的转化率自然就上去了，因为能通过注册这关的人本来就少了，而且这些人的意向都更强。
text_es: Y en la práctica, hablé de que casi siempre es más fácil hacer que sea más difícil realizar la acción justo antes de tu paso en el embudo (funnel) para aumentar tu tasa de conversión. Si hago que sea más difícil registrarse, va a ser muy fácil aumentar la tasa de registro a activación, porque simplemente tengo menos gente y las personas que lograron pasar tienen una intención mucho más alta.
context: Lenny asks Archie to elaborate on his philosophy about absolute numbers versus conversion rates in growth metrics. Archie provides a concrete example of how teams can game conversion rates by making earlier steps in the funnel more difficult. He explains that by making signup harder, fewer people will sign up, but those who do will be higher intent, which artificially increases the signup-to-activation conversion rate while actually hurting the business by reducing total activated users.
vocabulary_highlights: make it harder to do the thing, higher intent

speaker: Arielle Jackson
text: So over time, a word can come to mean something that is beyond what that actual word means. Like Disney means magic today. Volvo means safety. Those names are not good. If I just put it in a spreadsheet or one of those lists, no one would pick it. So that's kind of what I mean, that the name is just part of the overall marketing or the overall brand and a bad name with a really great company with great company strategy, great marketing is going to be great over time. And a good name is just going to help you, but I don't think a bad name is going to kill a good company.
text_ko: 시간이 지나면서 어떤 단어는 본래 뜻을 넘어서는 의미를 갖게 돼요. 예를 들어 디즈니(Disney)는 지금은 ‘마법’을, 볼보(Volvo)는 ‘안전’을 의미하죠. 그런 이름들은 처음 보면 별로인 경우가 많아요. 스프레드시트나 이름 목록에 그냥 넣어두면 아무도 고르지 않을 거예요. 제가 말하려는 건 이름은 전체 마케팅이나 브랜드의 일부일 뿐이라는 거예요. 이름이 별로여도 회사 전략이 훌륭하고 마케팅을 잘하면 시간이 지나면서 성공해요. 물론 좋은 이름은 도움이 되지만, 나쁜 이름 때문에 좋은 회사가 망하진 않을 거예요.
text_zh: 所以时间长了，一个词就会有超出它本身含义的意思。比如迪士尼现在就代表魔力，沃尔沃就代表安全。这些名字其实都不算好。如果我把它们放在表格里或者列个单子，没人会选它们。所以我的意思就是，名字只是整体营销或者整体品牌的一部分，一个烂名字配上真正厉害的公司、厉害的公司战略、厉害的营销，时间长了也会很棒。好名字只是会帮到你，但我觉得烂名字不会搞垮一个好公司。
text_es: Con el tiempo, una palabra puede llegar a significar algo que va más allá de lo que realmente significa esa palabra. Como Disney hoy significa magia. Volvo significa seguridad. Esos nombres no son buenos en sí mismos. Si los pusiera en una hoja de cálculo o en una de esas listas, nadie los elegiría. Entonces a eso me refiero, que el nombre es solo parte del marketing general o de la marca en general, y un mal nombre con una empresa realmente genial, con una gran estrategia empresarial y gran marketing, va a triunfar con el tiempo. Y un buen nombre simplemente te va a ayudar, pero no creo que un mal nombre vaya a hundir a una buena empresa.
context: Lenny is asking Arielle about the importance of company names and whether a bad name can hurt a startup. Arielle explains that while a great name can help with word-of-mouth and memorability, a bad name won't necessarily doom a good company with strong strategy and marketing. She uses Disney and Volvo as examples - names that weren't inherently good but became powerful through consistent branding over time, with Disney now meaning 'magic' and Volvo representing 'safety.'
vocabulary_highlights: come to mean, in a spreadsheet, marketing work for you, kill a good company

speaker: Arielle Jackson
text: And I personally tend to like those kinds of names that are suggestive or evocative, where when I tell you what the company does, you're like, oh, that makes sense. But it's not that what the name is tells you exactly what the company does. Another company that has a good name that you and I have both worked with is Maven. Maven is a Yiddish word that means one who understands and it means specifically one who understands because they've done something, they've acquired the skills or knowledge over time. And I just think that's such a cool name for a platform that allows X operators or current operators to teach their skills to other people through cohort based classes.
text_ko: 저는 개인적으로 회사 이름이 암시적이거나 감성을 자극하는 그런 이름을 좋아해요. 회사가 어떤 일을 하는지 말해주면, "아, 그럴듯하네!"라고 느끼게 되는 그런 이름이요. 하지만 이름이 회사의 모든 걸 정확히 설명해주지는 않아요. 우리가 함께 일해본 좋은 이름의 또 다른 회사는 Maven이에요. Maven은 이디시어로 '이해하는 사람'이라는 뜻인데, 특히 어떤 일을 해본 경험이 있어서 그 지식이나 기술을 쌓은 사람을 의미해요. 그래서 X 운영자들이나 현재 운영자들이 코호트 기반 수업을 통해 다른 사람들에게 자신의 기술을 가르칠 수 있는 플랫폼에 정말 잘 어울리는 멋진 이름이라고 생각해요.
text_zh: 我个人比较喜欢那种有暗示性或者能引发联想的名字，就是当我告诉你这家公司是做什么的时候，你会恍然大悟："哦，原来如此！" 但这个名字本身并不会直接告诉你公司的具体业务。我们俩都合作过的Maven就是个很好的例子，名字起得特别棒。Maven是个意第绪语词汇，意思是"内行人"，特指那种通过实践获得技能和知识的专家。我觉得这个名字对他们的平台来说简直太贴切了——让各个行业的从业者或者现任运营人员通过小班课程(cohort based classes)把自己的技能传授给别人。
text_es: Y a mí personalmente me encantan ese tipo de nombres que son sugestivos o evocativos, donde cuando te digo a qué se dedica la empresa, tú dices "ah, claro, tiene sentido". Pero no es que el nombre te diga exactamente qué hace la empresa. Otra empresa que tiene un nombre genial y con la que hemos trabajado los dos es Maven. Maven es una palabra en yiddish que significa "alguien que entiende" y específicamente se refiere a alguien que entiende porque ya lo ha hecho, porque ha adquirido las habilidades o el conocimiento con el tiempo. Y me parece un nombre súper cool para una plataforma que permite que ex operadores o operadores actuales enseñen sus habilidades a otras personas a través de clases en cohortes (cohort-based classes).
context: Lenny asks Arielle what makes a good name for a startup or product. Arielle explains her preference for suggestive or evocative names - names that make sense once you understand what the company does, but don't literally describe the service. She uses Maven as an example, explaining how the Yiddish word meaning 'one who understands through experience' perfectly fits a platform where experienced operators teach cohort-based classes to others.
vocabulary_highlights: suggestive or evocative, acquired the skills, cohort based classes

speaker: Arielle Jackson
text: My take on empty vessel names is they can be really memorable and they can be evocative of the emotion, but you have to do a lot more marketing work over time to make it mean something. So if I say Yahoo today, we know it's that search engine we use before we all switch to Google and we have the purple color in our head, and we think about what it meant at the time that we might have used it, but it took a lot of marketing dollars and a lot of time for that word to be in that.
text_ko: 제 생각에는 빈 그릇 같은 이름(empty vessel names)은 정말 기억에 남고 감정을 불러일으킬 수 있어요. 하지만 시간이 지나면서 그 이름이 실제로 의미를 갖게 만들려면 훨씬 더 많은 마케팅 노력이 필요해요. 예를 들어 지금 제가 'Yahoo'라고 하면, 우리한테는 다들 구글로 갈아타기 전쯤에 쓰던 그 검색 엔진이 떠오르고 보라색이 머릿속에 남고, 그때 그 이름이 어떤 의미였는지도 떠오르죠. 그런데 그 단어가 그런 의미를 갖게 되기까지는 많은 마케팅 비용과 시간이 들었어요.
text_zh: 我觉得这种空白容器型的品牌名(empty vessel names)吧，确实容易让人记住，也能勾起情感共鸣，但是你得花大量的营销功夫和时间才能让它有意义。比如说我现在提到雅虎，我们都知道这是我们在转用谷歌之前用的那个搜索引擎，脑子里会想起那个紫色，会想起我们当时用它时的感觉，但这个词能有这些联想，背后可是砸了不少营销费用和时间的。
text_es: Mi opinión sobre los nombres vacíos es que pueden ser súper memorables y pueden evocar emociones, pero tienes que hacer muchísimo más trabajo de marketing a lo largo del tiempo para que signifiquen algo. O sea, si hoy digo Yahoo, sabemos que es ese buscador que usábamos antes de que todos nos pasáramos a Google, se nos viene a la cabeza el color morado, y pensamos en lo que significaba en esa época cuando lo usábamos, pero costó un montón de dinero en marketing y muchísimo tiempo para que esa palabra llegara a representar todo eso.
context: Lenny asks about nonsense words as company names like Yahoo and Google. Arielle explains the concept of 'empty vessel names' - names that don't have inherent meaning but can become powerful brand assets. However, she warns that these names require significantly more marketing investment and time to build meaning, using Yahoo as an example of how much effort was needed to make that meaningless word represent a search engine in people's minds.
vocabulary_highlights: empty vessel names, evocative of the emotion, marketing work, marketing dollars

speaker: Arielle Jackson
text: Almost always when someone comes to me and says, I'm ready to announce, we go back to positioning first. Also make sure that your website is ready for the traffic you're going to drive to it, that you're not driving traffic to a name that you're going to later scrap. Are you really ready for this? So go back to all the other things we discussed first and then having realistic expectations about the outlets that will cover you and the time it will take to get them.
text_ko: 거의 항상 누군가가 "이제 발표할 준비됐어요"라고 하면, 우리는 먼저 포지셔닝(positioning)으로 다시 돌아가요. 또 웹사이트(website)가 유입될 트래픽(traffic)을 감당할 준비가 되어 있는지, 나중에 버릴 이름에 트래픽을 몰아주는 건 아닌지도 확인하세요. 진짜로 준비됐나요? 그러니까 먼저 앞서 얘기했던 다른 것들을 다 점검하고, 당신을 다뤄줄 매체(outlets)에 대해 현실적인 기대를 갖고 그들이 보도해주기까지 걸리는 시간도 고려하세요.
text_zh: 几乎每次有人跟我说"我准备好发布了"，我都会让他们先回头看看定位(positioning)做得怎么样。还有，你得确保你的网站能承受得住即将涌入的流量，别把流量导到一个你后来要废掉的名字上。你真的准备好了吗？所以先把我们之前聊的那些事情都搞定，然后对媒体报道和时间周期要有个现实的预期。
text_es: Casi siempre cuando alguien viene y me dice "ya estoy listo para hacer el anuncio", volvemos primero al tema del posicionamiento. También asegúrate de que tu sitio web esté preparado para todo el tráfico que vas a generar, que no estés enviando gente a un nombre que después vas a cambiar. ¿De verdad estás listo para esto? Así que regresa primero a todas esas otras cosas que hablamos y luego ten expectativas realistas sobre qué medios te van a cubrir y cuánto tiempo te va a tomar conseguirlos.
context: Lenny asks Arielle for tactical advice on getting PR for startups before launch. Arielle emphasizes that founders often rush to announce without proper preparation. She stresses the importance of having clear positioning first, ensuring your website can handle traffic, and having realistic expectations about which media outlets will actually cover an early-stage startup and how long the PR process takes.
vocabulary_highlights: ready to announce, go back to positioning, drive traffic to, scrap, realistic expectations

speaker: Arielle Jackson
text: These days for early stage startups, we're almost always running the launch announcement as an exclusive, which means you give the news to a single outlet. And they're the only ones who get to write about it. You can obviously still do all your owned and operated stuff, your blog, your social, your investors, your friends and family, but they're the only like news outlet who gets to write about it.
text_ko: 요즘 초기 단계 스타트업(early-stage startups)들은 출시 발표(launch announcement)를 거의 항상 단독 공개(exclusive)로 해요. 한 매체(outlet)에만 먼저 뉴스를 줘서 그 매체만 보도하게 하는 방식이죠. 물론 자체 채널(owned and operated)인 블로그나 소셜, 투자자들, 가족·지인에게는 여전히 알릴 수 있어요. 다만 뉴스 매체 중에서는 그 한 곳만 기사를 쓸 수 있게 하는 거예요.
text_zh: 现在对于早期创业公司来说，我们发布产品的时候基本上都是搞独家报道，就是说你把消息只给一家媒体。只有他们能写这个新闻。当然了，你自己的渠道还是可以用的，比如你们的博客啊、社交媒体啊、投资人那边啊、亲朋好友啊，但是在新闻媒体里面，就只有这一家能报道。
text_es: Hoy en día para las startups en etapa temprana, casi siempre manejamos el anuncio de lanzamiento como una exclusiva, o sea que le das la noticia a un solo medio. Y son los únicos que pueden escribir sobre eso. Obviamente todavía puedes hacer todo lo tuyo - tu blog, tus redes, tus inversionistas, familia y amigos - pero son el único medio de comunicación que tiene derecho a escribir la nota.
context: Arielle is explaining how PR strategy has evolved for early-stage startups. She describes how the traditional approach of briefing multiple outlets under embargo no longer works effectively. Instead, modern startup PR typically involves giving exclusive coverage rights to a single media outlet, while still allowing the company to use their own channels (blog, social media, investor updates) to share the news.
vocabulary_highlights: running the launch announcement, as an exclusive, owned and operated stuff

speaker: Arielle Jackson
text: The last thing is really about making what you do interesting and relevant so that it's not just interesting and relevant to you and the three other people who worked there at the time, but interesting to all the readers of whatever outlet you're trying to target. We turned all of our customers into heroes and went after local press. Most PR firms that service the tech community aren't experts in local press, but if you have a way to make some connections with some local press, they are the ones hungry for these stories more than the New York Times and the Wall Street Journal.
text_ko: 마지막으로 중요한 건, 당신이 하는 일을 흥미롭고 관련성 있게 만드는 거예요. 그래야 당시 함께 일하던 당신과 다른 세 명만 흥미로워하는 게 아니라, 당신이 공략하려는 매체(outlet)의 모든 독자들에게도 흥미롭고 의미 있게 다가가죠. 저희는 모든 고객을 영웅으로 만들고 지역 언론(local press)을 적극적으로 공략했어요. 기술 업계(tech community)를 상대하는 대부분의 PR 회사(PR firms)는 지역 언론에 대해서는 전문가가 아닌 경우가 많은데, 만약 지역 언론과 연결될 방법이 있다면 그런 매체들이 뉴욕타임스나 월스트리트저널보다 이런 이야기들을 더 갈망하더라고요.
text_zh: 最后一点就是要让你做的事情变得有意思、有价值，不能只是你们几个当事人觉得有意思，而是要让你想打入的那些媒体的所有读者都觉得有意思。我们把所有客户都包装成了英雄人物，然后专门找本地媒体。大部分服务科技圈的公关公司其实都不太懂本地媒体这一套，但如果你能想办法跟本地媒体搭上线，他们其实比《纽约时报》和《华尔街日报》更渴望这种故事。
text_es: Lo último que te quiero decir es que tienes que hacer que lo que haces sea interesante y relevante, no solo para ti y los tres que trabajaban ahí en ese momento, sino para todos los lectores del medio al que le quieres apuntar. Nosotros convertimos a todos nuestros clientes en héroes y nos fuimos por la prensa local. La mayoría de las agencias de relaciones públicas que atienden al sector tech no son expertas en medios locales, pero si logras hacer algunas conexiones con prensa local, ellos son los que están hambrientos de estas historias, mucho más que el New York Times o el Wall Street Journal.
context: Arielle is providing PR advice about making startup stories newsworthy to journalists and their audiences. She explains that founders need to think beyond their own perspective and create stories that appeal to broader readerships. She shares a strategy from her Square days of making customers the heroes of stories and targeting local press, which is often more accessible and eager for startup stories than major national publications.
vocabulary_highlights: turned all of our customers into heroes, went after local press, service the tech community, hungry for these stories

speaker: Asha Sharma
text: Because these models are so effective at this point, you want to start to tune them to certain types of outcomes. All of a sudden, these are these living organisms that just get better with the more interactions that happen. I think this is the new IP of every single company products that think and live and learn.
text_ko: 이 모델(models)들이 이제 워낙 효과적이어서, 특정한 결과에 맞게 튜닝(tuning)하기 시작해야 해요. 어느 순간부터 이건 상호작용이 늘어날수록 더 좋아지는 살아있는 유기체처럼 됐어요. 생각하고, 살아있고, 학습하는 모든 회사 제품들에겐 이게 새로운 지적재산(IP)이 될 거라고 생각해요.
text_zh: 现在这些模型已经非常厉害了，你就想开始调教它们，让它们产生特定的结果。突然间，这些东西就像活的生物一样，互动得越多就越聪明。我觉得这就是每个公司的新知识产权(IP)——能思考、能存活、能学习的产品。
text_es: Como estos modelos son tan efectivos ya en este punto, quieres empezar a ajustarlos para ciertos tipos de resultados. De repente, se convierten en estos organismos vivos que mejoran mientras más interacciones tengan. Creo que esta es la nueva propiedad intelectual (IP) de todas las empresas: productos que piensan, viven y aprenden.
context: Lenny asks Asha about her concept of moving from "product as artifact to product as organism." Asha explains how AI models have evolved beyond static software products that are shipped once and occasionally updated. Instead, modern AI products continuously improve through user interactions and feedback loops, creating what she calls "living organisms" that adapt and learn over time.
vocabulary_highlights: tune them to certain types of outcomes, living organisms, new IP

speaker: Asha Sharma
text: We're approaching this world in which the marginal cost of the good output is approaching zero. We're going to see exponential demand for productivity and outputs. The way that you scale to that is with agents. When all of that happens, the org chart starts to become the work chart. You just don't need as many layers.
text_ko: 우리는 산출물의 한계비용(marginal cost)이 거의 0에 가까워지는 세상으로 접어들고 있어요. 생산성(productivity)과 산출물(outputs)에 대한 수요가 기하급수적으로 늘어날 거예요. 그걸 확장(scale)하는 방법은 에이전트(agents)를 활용하는 거고요. 그런 변화가 일어나면 조직도(org chart)가 곧 실제 일(work chart)이 되기 시작해요. 그래서 계층 구조가 그렇게 많이 필요하지 않게 돼요.
text_zh: 我们正在进入一个边际成本(marginal cost)接近零的时代。生产力和产出的需求会呈指数级增长。要应对这种规模，就得靠智能代理(agents)。当这一切发生时，组织架构图基本上就变成了工作流程图。你根本不需要那么多层级了。
text_es: Nos estamos acercando a un mundo donde el costo marginal de producir buenos resultados se está volviendo casi cero. Vamos a ver una demanda exponencial de productividad y resultados. La forma de escalar a ese nivel es con agentes. Cuando todo eso pase, el organigrama empieza a convertirse en el diagrama de trabajo. Simplemente ya no necesitas tantos niveles jerárquicos.
context: Lenny asks Asha about her prediction that we're just starting to scratch the surface of what an agentic society looks like. Asha explains her vision of the future where AI agents dramatically reduce the cost of producing quality work outputs, leading to exponential demand for productivity. She predicts this will fundamentally change organizational structures from traditional hierarchies to task-based work assignments.
vocabulary_highlights: marginal cost, approaching zero, scale to that, org chart starts to become the work chart

speaker: Asha Sharma
text: I think everybody is using some sort of co-pilot or sort of AI in their day-to-day workflows like job one, so everyone's not afraid of it, understands how we can raise the ceiling and lower the floor for all sorts of skills and tasks.
text_ko: 제 생각에는 거의 모든 사람이 일상 업무에서 코파일럿(co-pilot)이나 인공지능(AI) 같은 걸 이미 쓰고 있어요. 그래서 다들 이제 두려워하지 않고, 이런 도구로 여러 기술과 업무의 최고 성과는 끌어올리고 최소 수행 수준(진입 장벽)은 낮출 수 있다는 걸 이해하고 있어요.
text_zh: 我觉得现在大家在日常工作中都会用到一些副驾驶(co-pilot)或者AI工具，这已经是基本操作了，所以大家都不怕这些技术，也明白怎么用它们来提升上限、降低门槛，让各种技能和任务都变得更容易上手。
text_es: Creo que todo el mundo ya está usando algún tipo de copiloto o IA en su trabajo del día a día como prioridad número uno, entonces ya nadie le tiene miedo, entiende cómo podemos subir el techo y bajar el piso para todo tipo de habilidades y tareas.
context: Lenny asks what patterns distinguish companies that successfully build AI products from those that struggle. Asha outlines the first step successful companies take: ensuring all employees become AI fluent by using AI tools in their daily work. This removes fear and helps everyone understand AI's potential to enhance capabilities across different skill levels and tasks.
vocabulary_highlights: job one, raise the ceiling and lower the floor

speaker: Asha Sharma
text: I really believe in the concept of the full stack builder. You're seeing it with a bunch of the AI native companies that are coming up. I'm even seeing it in enterprises that have been around for 50 years starting to operate in that way. And I think that gives you velocity and throughput and then gives you the whole loop to start to actually metabolize and go through that much faster.
text_ko: 저는 풀 스택 빌더(full stack builder)라는 개념을 정말 믿어요. 요즘 생겨나는 AI 네이티브(AI native) 기업들에서 그 모습이 보이고 있고, 50년 넘은 기업들조차 그렇게 운영하기 시작하는 걸 보고 있어요. 그런 접근이 속도와 처리량(velocity and throughput)을 높여주고, 전체 루프(loop)를 만들어 실제로 그걸 더 빠르게 내재화(metabolize)하고 과정을 훨씬 빨리 돌릴 수 있게 해줘요.
text_zh: 我特别认同全栈建设者(full stack builder)这个理念。你看现在很多AI原生公司都是这么做的，连那些有五十年历史的老企业都开始这样运作了。我觉得这样能让你的执行速度更快，产出更高，而且能形成一个完整的闭环，让你消化吸收、迭代优化的速度大大提升。
text_es: Yo creo mucho en el concepto del desarrollador full stack (full stack builder). Lo estás viendo con un montón de estas empresas nativas de IA que están surgiendo. Incluso lo estoy viendo en empresas que llevan 50 años operando y están empezando a trabajar de esa manera. Y creo que eso te da velocidad y productividad, y luego te da todo el ciclo completo para realmente procesar y avanzar mucho más rápido.
context: Lenny asks about patterns in successful AI companies, and Asha discusses how traditional organizational structures are changing. She explains that the traditional product development process involves too many layers and touchpoints to keep up with rapidly evolving AI technology. The solution is "full stack builders" - individuals who can work across multiple disciplines rather than being confined to narrow functional roles.
vocabulary_highlights: full stack builder, velocity and throughput, metabolize and go through

speaker: Asha Sharma
text: We think about it as what season are we in? Season one might've been prototyping of AI and then it was all around models and reasoning models, and now it's the advent of agents.
text_ko: 우리는 지금 어떤 시즌에 있나 생각해요. 첫 시즌은 인공지능(AI) 프로토타이핑(prototyping) 단계였고, 그다음에는 모델(models)과 추론 모델(reasoning models)이 중심이었어요. 지금은 에이전트(agents)가 본격적으로 등장한 시기예요.
text_zh: 我们是这么想的，现在我们处在哪个阶段？第一阶段可能是AI原型开发，然后就是各种模型和推理模型(reasoning models)的阶段，现在我们迎来了智能代理(agents)的时代。
text_es: Lo vemos como ¿en qué temporada estamos? La primera temporada pudo haber sido el prototipado de la IA, después todo giró en torno a los modelos y modelos de razonamiento, y ahora estamos en la llegada de los agentes.
context: Lenny asks how anyone can plan roadmaps when the AI landscape changes so rapidly with new model releases. Asha explains Microsoft's approach to strategic planning in the fast-moving AI space. Instead of traditional fixed timeframes, they think in "seasons" - periods defined by major technological or market shifts that can last anywhere from three months to a year.
vocabulary_highlights: advent of agents

speaker: Asha Sharma
text: I've learned that optimism is a renewable resource. This company for 50 years has had every reason not to succeed and it has even as it's had early success in the AI era and challenges and other successes and the space is developing so quickly, I think that his ability to generate energy and to use his optimism to renew everybody's dedication to the mission is unbelievable.
text_ko: 저는 낙관주의가 재생 가능한 자원이라는 걸 배웠어요. 이 회사는 지난 50년 동안 성공하지 못할 이유가 수도 없이 많았는데도, AI 시대(AI era)에 초기에 성공을 거두기도 했고 여러 도전과 또 다른 성과를 겪으면서 분야가 너무 빠르게 변하는 상황에서도, 그가 에너지를 만들어내고 자신의 낙관주의로 모두의 사명(mission)에 대한 헌신을 다시 불러일으키는 능력은 정말 놀라워요.
text_zh: 我发现乐观主义其实是可以不断更新的资源。这家公司50年来遇到过各种各样本来可能让它失败的理由，但它还是挺过来了。哪怕在AI时代早期取得成功，后来又遇到挑战，然后又有其他成功，整个行业发展得这么快，我觉得他那种能够激发团队活力，用自己的乐观精神重新点燃大家对使命投入的能力，真的是太厉害了。
text_es: He aprendido que el optimismo es un recurso renovable. Esta empresa durante 50 años ha tenido todas las razones del mundo para no triunfar y aun así lo ha logrado, incluso cuando tuvo éxito temprano en la era de la IA y desafíos y otros logros, y el sector está evolucionando tan rápido que creo que su capacidad para generar energía y usar su optimismo para renovar la dedicación de todos hacia la misión es increíble.
context: Lenny asks what Asha has learned from working closely with Satya Nadella, Microsoft's CEO. Asha shares her key observation about his leadership style, particularly how he maintains and spreads optimism throughout the organization. She emphasizes how Satya uses optimism as a tool to continuously re-energize teams and maintain commitment to the company's mission, even during challenging periods.
vocabulary_highlights: renewable resource, generate energy, renew everybody's dedication

speaker: Asha Sharma
text: I believe we will see just as much money spent on post-training as we will on pre-training and in the future, more on post-training. We talked a little bit about Nathan Lambert's study where his review was that when a model hits 30 billion parameters, it makes more sense to fine-tune and optimize that 50% of developers according to surveys are now fine-tuning.
text_ko: 저는 사전 학습(pre-training)만큼 사후 학습(post-training)에 돈이 들어갈 거라고 봐요. 앞으로는 오히려 사후 학습에 더 많이 투자할 것 같아요. 네이선 램버트(Nathan Lambert)의 연구를 잠깐 얘기했는데, 그 연구는 모델이 파라미터(parameters) 300억 개쯤 되면 파인튜닝(fine-tuning)과 최적화(optimize)가 더 합리적이라고 결론 내렸어요. 설문조사에 따르면 개발자의 약 50%가 지금 파인튜닝을 하고 있다고 하더라고요.
text_zh: 我觉得未来在后训练(post-training)上花的钱会跟预训练(pre-training)一样多，甚至后面可能后训练花得更多。我们之前聊过Nathan Lambert的那个研究，他的结论是模型一旦到了300亿参数，做微调(fine-tune)和优化就更划算了。调研显示现在有50%的开发者都在搞微调。
text_es: Creo que vamos a ver tanto dinero invertido en el post-entrenamiento como en el pre-entrenamiento, y en el futuro, incluso más en el post-entrenamiento. Hablamos un poco del estudio de Nathan Lambert donde concluyó que cuando un modelo llega a los 30 mil millones de parámetros, tiene más sentido hacer fine-tuning y optimizar. Y según las encuestas, el 50% de los desarrolladores ya están haciendo fine-tuning.
context: Asha shares her prediction about a major shift in AI development investment priorities. Pre-training involves the initial creation of foundation models with massive compute requirements, while post-training involves customizing existing models through techniques like fine-tuning and reinforcement learning. She argues that economic and practical factors are driving companies to focus more resources on adapting existing powerful models rather than building new ones from scratch.
vocabulary_highlights: post-training, pre-training, fine-tune and optimize

speaker: Austin Hay
speaker_expertise: Marketing Strategy, Growth Strategy, Data Analytics
text: From 2010 to 2020, we had the golden years of deterministic matching where it was very easy to run an ad and understand with precision who installed the app. Maybe you didn't know their name, but you actually would know their IDFA and you could tie that to their PII. You can't do that anymore. So, what that means is these ad networks are becoming more complex, sophisticated, and interesting, right at the same time that it's harder for marketers to really understand how they're spending money.
text_ko: 2010년부터 2020년까지는 결정론적 매칭(deterministic matching)의 황금기였어요. 광고를 내면 누가 앱을 설치했는지 아주 정확히 파악하기가 쉬웠죠. 이름은 몰라도 그 사람의 광고 식별자(IDFA)를 알고, 그걸 개인 식별 정보(PII, personally identifiable information)와 연결할 수 있었어요. 이제는 그게 안 돼요. 그래서 광고 네트워크(ad networks)들이 더 복잡하고 정교해지면서 흥미로워지고 있는데, 마케터들이 실제로 돈을 어떻게 쓰는지 이해하기는 훨씬 더 어려워졌어요.
text_zh: 从2010年到2020年，那是确定性匹配(deterministic matching)的黄金时代，跑个广告就能很精准地知道是谁下载了你的应用。虽然你可能不知道用户的真实姓名，但你能拿到他们的IDFA，然后把这个跟个人身份信息(PII)关联起来。现在这套玩法行不通了。这就意味着，广告网络(ad networks)变得越来越复杂、越来越高端，与此同时，营销人员却更难搞清楚自己的钱到底花到哪儿去了。
text_es: Desde el 2010 hasta el 2020, tuvimos la época dorada del deterministic matching, donde era súper fácil lanzar un anuncio y entender con precisión exacta quién se descargó la app. Tal vez no sabías su nombre, pero sí sabías su IDFA y podías conectar eso con su información personal. Ya no se puede hacer eso. Entonces, lo que significa es que estas redes publicitarias se están volviendo más complejas, sofisticadas e interesantes, justo al mismo tiempo que se les hace más difícil a los marketers entender realmente en qué se están gastando el dinero.
context: Austin is opening the podcast by explaining the dramatic shift in mobile app attribution that has fundamentally changed marketing technology. IDFA (Identifier for Advertisers) was Apple's unique identifier that allowed precise tracking of users from ads to app installs. PII stands for Personally Identifiable Information. Austin explains how the elimination of deterministic matching (precise, definitive tracking) has created a paradox where ad networks are becoming more sophisticated while marketers have less visibility into their spending effectiveness.
vocabulary_highlights: golden years, deterministic matching, tie that to their PII, right at the same time

speaker: Austin Hay
speaker_expertise: Marketing Strategy, Growth Strategy, Data Analytics
text: Marketing technology is like this very amorphous, cross-functional discipline that lives at the crossroads of product and growth and engineering and marketing. It brings together processes and systems from a wide range of disciplines. And I think really the way to think about marketing technology is it's a product manager whose specific role and focus is the system or the third party or first party platform.
text_ko: 마케팅 테크(marketing technology)는 굉장히 모호하고 크로스펑셔널(cross-functional)한 분야로, 제품(product)과 그로스(growth), 엔지니어링, 마케팅이 만나는 교차점에 있어요. 다양한 영역의 프로세스와 시스템을 한데 모으는 역할을 하고요. 제 생각엔 마케팅 테크를 이해하는 가장 좋은 방식은, 그 역할과 초점이 시스템이나 서드파티(third-party) 혹은 퍼스트파티(first-party) 플랫폼에 있는 제품 매니저(product manager)라고 보는 거예요.
text_zh: 营销技术(marketing technology)这个东西其实挺模糊的，它是个跨部门的领域，处在产品、增长、工程和营销的交叉点上。它把各个不同领域的流程和系统都整合在一起。我觉得理解营销技术最好的方式就是，把它想象成一个产品经理，只不过这个产品经理专门负责系统平台，不管是第三方的还是自家的平台。
text_es: La tecnología de marketing es como una disciplina muy fluida y transversal que está justo en el cruce entre producto, crecimiento, ingeniería y marketing. Junta procesos y sistemas de un montón de áreas diferentes. Y yo creo que realmente la forma de pensar en la tecnología de marketing es como un product manager cuyo rol específico y enfoque es el sistema o la plataforma, ya sea de terceros o propia.
context: Lenny asks Austin to define what MarTech (Marketing Technology) is and what someone in MarTech does. Austin is explaining that MarTech is an interdisciplinary field that sits between multiple departments - product, growth, engineering, and marketing. He describes it as managing both third-party tools (external platforms like analytics or email tools) and first-party solutions (custom-built internal systems), similar to how a product manager approaches their role.
vocabulary_highlights: very amorphous, crossroads, third party or first party platform
topics: Product Management, Growth & Marketing, Leadership & Management

speaker: Austin Hay
speaker_expertise: Marketing Strategy, Growth Strategy, Data Analytics
text: And everybody thinks that marketing technology is just the third party tools, but actually it's designing, architecting and building that stuff on top of your third party tools. That's how you actually have a lot of velocity is thinking about not just build versus buy. It's build and buy now. So, you buy the tool to get 90% of the way there and then you build the cool thing on top with the other 10%.
text_ko: 사람들은 마케팅 기술(marketing technology)이 그냥 서드파티 툴(third-party tools)이라고만 생각하지만, 사실은 그 위에 무엇을 설계(designing)하고, 아키텍처(architecting)를 잡아서 실제로 구현(building)하는 일이에요. 속도(velocity)를 내려면 단순히 '구축 대 구매(build vs buy)'만 고민할 게 아니라, 지금은 '구축도 하고 구매도 하는(build and buy)' 접근이 필요해요. 툴을 사서 90%는 해결하고, 나머지 10%를 직접 만들어서 멋진 기능을 얹는 식이에요.
text_zh: 大家都觉得营销技术(marketing technology)就是那些第三方工具，但其实真正的核心是在这些第三方工具基础上去设计、架构和开发东西。要想真正提高效率，不能只想着是自己开发还是直接买，现在得两手抓——既要买也要开发。你买个工具能解决90%的问题，然后在上面开发点酷炫的功能把剩下10%搞定。
text_es: Y todo el mundo piensa que la tecnología de marketing son solo las herramientas de terceros, pero en realidad se trata de diseñar, estructurar y construir cosas encima de esas herramientas que ya tienes. Así es como realmente logras mucha velocidad (velocity): no se trata solo de pensar en construir versus comprar. Ahora es construir y comprar a la vez. O sea, compras la herramienta para llegar al 90% del camino y luego construyes la parte genial encima con ese otro 10%.
context: Austin is explaining the slice of work that a MarTech person would take from a growth team when companies reach the point of needing dedicated MarTech support. He's describing how MarTech involves both purchasing third-party tools and building custom solutions on top of them. The "build versus buy" decision framework traditionally meant choosing one or the other, but Austin advocates for "build and buy" - purchasing tools for the foundation and building custom features on top.
vocabulary_highlights: have a lot of velocity, build versus buy, build and buy, get 90% of the way there
topics: Product Management, Strategy & Planning, Growth & Marketing

speaker: Austin Hay
speaker_expertise: Marketing Strategy, Growth Strategy, Data Analytics
text: I think all marketing technologists at some level are ICs. I think it's a great job personally, because I get to be an IC and a manager. You have to be an IC in that, you are the most senior technical expert on all first party and third party systems. So, you have to know really well how third party tools work and you don't know that without doing the work yourself.
text_ko: 저는 모든 마케팅 테크놀로지스트(marketing technologists)가 어느 정도는 다들 IC(Individual Contributor)라고 생각해요. 개인적으로 이 일은 정말 좋은 직무예요 — IC이면서 매니저를 겸할 수 있어서요. 그 역할에서는 IC로서 직접 기여해야 해요. 퍼스트파티(first-party)와 서드파티(third-party) 시스템 전반에 대해 가장 선임된 기술 전문가거든요. 그래서 서드파티 도구(third-party tools)가 어떻게 작동하는지 정말 잘 알아야 하고, 직접 해보지 않으면 그걸 알 수 없어요.
text_zh: 我觉得所有的营销技术专家(marketing technologist)某种程度上都是个人贡献者(IC)。我个人认为这是个很棒的工作，因为我既能做IC又能做管理。你必须得是个IC，因为你要成为所有第一方和第三方系统最资深的技术专家。所以你得真正了解第三方工具是怎么运作的，不亲自动手你是搞不明白的。
text_es: Creo que todos los tecnólogos de marketing a cierto nivel son contribuidores individuales (ICs). Personalmente pienso que es un trabajo genial, porque puedo ser IC y gerente a la vez. Tienes que ser IC en el sentido de que eres el experto técnico más senior en todos los sistemas propios y de terceros. Entonces, tienes que saber muy bien cómo funcionan las herramientas de terceros y eso no lo aprendes sin meter las manos en la masa tú mismo.
context: Lenny asks whether MarTech people do the work themselves or build teams with engineers. Austin explains that MarTech professionals are Individual Contributors (ICs) who must maintain hands-on technical expertise. Unlike traditional management roles where you might delegate technical work, MarTech requires you to be the senior technical expert on both internal systems (first party) and external tools (third party), which means staying involved in the actual implementation work.

speaker: Austin Hay
speaker_expertise: Marketing Strategy, Growth Strategy, Data Analytics
text: I almost view them like a true quarterback every [inaudible] says people are quarterbacks. But really marketing technology because it lives between so many departments, it plays that role of having to call plays and pull on different departments.
text_ko: 저는 사실 그걸 진짜 쿼터백(quarterback)처럼 보는 편이에요. 사람들이 다들 쿼터백이라고 말하긴 하는데, 마케팅 테크놀로지(marketing technology)는 여러 부서 사이에 걸쳐 있어서 전술을 지시하고 다양한 부서를 끌어모아 조율하는 역할을 해요.
text_zh: 我觉得他们就像真正的四分卫(quarterback)一样，虽然每个人都说自己是四分卫。但营销技术因为要跟这么多部门打交道，确实起到了那种统筹协调的作用，需要制定策略，还要调动各个部门的资源。
text_es: Yo casi los veo como un verdadero mariscal de campo (quarterback), porque todo el mundo dice que la gente son mariscales de campo. Pero realmente la tecnología de marketing, como está entre tantos departamentos, juega ese papel de tener que dirigir las jugadas y coordinar con diferentes áreas.
context: Austin continues explaining the cross-functional nature of MarTech roles. He's describing how MarTech professionals need to coordinate across multiple departments - they might need to work with the head of revenue operations to change something in Salesforce, talk to the VP of product for platform changes, or rely on the data team for resources. The quarterback analogy emphasizes how they orchestrate plays across different functional areas rather than having direct authority over team members.
vocabulary_highlights: call plays, pull on different departments

speaker: Austin Hay
speaker_expertise: Marketing Strategy, Growth Strategy, Data Analytics
text: I tend to take a little bit of a different approach than most, which is like I think you should always be thinking about the future. That doesn't necessarily mean you should make design choices that over index towards the future so much that you miss product market fit or you make poor product decisions. But when you set up tools and you pick tools and you implement them, you should be thinking, what's going to happen a year from now if I don't change anything?
text_ko: 저는 보통 사람들과 조금 다르게 접근해요. 항상 미래를 생각해야 한다고 보는 편인데, 그렇다고 해서 미래에 지나치게 치우친 설계 선택으로 제품-시장 적합도(product-market fit)를 놓치거나 잘못된 제품 결정을 내려도 된다는 건 아니에요. 다만 도구를 고르고 도입해서 구현할 때는 '아무것도 안 바꾸면 1년 뒤에 어떻게 될까?'를 항상 염두에 둬야 해요.
text_zh: 我的做法跟大多数人不太一样，我觉得应该时刻想着未来。当然这不是说你要过度迎合未来，搞得连产品市场契合度(product market fit)都找不到，或者做出一堆糟糕的产品决策。但是当你在搭建工具、选择工具、落地实施的时候，你得想想，如果我一年内什么都不改，会发生什么？
text_es: Mi enfoque suele ser un poco diferente al de la mayoría. Yo creo que siempre hay que estar pensando en el futuro. Eso no significa que tengas que tomar decisiones de diseño que se enfoquen tanto en el futuro que termines perdiendo el product market fit o tomando malas decisiones de producto. Pero cuando configuras herramientas, las eliges y las implementas, tienes que preguntarte: ¿qué va a pasar dentro de un año si no cambio nada?
context: Austin is explaining his philosophy for how growth managers should think about MarTech decisions beyond just immediate needs. He's addressing the balance between short-term execution and long-term planning. "Over index towards the future" means focusing too heavily on future needs at the expense of current priorities like achieving product-market fit. Austin advocates for making tool decisions that consider future scalability without sacrificing present objectives.
vocabulary_highlights: over index towards the future, product market fit
topics: Strategy & Planning, Decision Making, Product Management

speaker: Austin Hay
speaker_expertise: Marketing Strategy, Growth Strategy, Data Analytics
text: I think the most superhuman user acquisition people out there are engineers and they don't need a marketing technologist because they set up the tool themself. They know how the paid campaign runs and they just do it all. And you'll typically find these super humans at small startups where the engineer is just told by the co-founder, hey, go figure out how Facebook ads work.
text_ko: 제 생각에는 가장 대단한 사용자 확보(user acquisition) 담당자들은 엔지니어들이에요. 마케팅 테크놀로지스트(marketing technologist)가 따로 필요 없어요 — 도구를 스스로 세팅해 버리니까요. 유료 캠페인(paid campaign)이 어떻게 돌아가는지 알고, 그냥 전부 다 해버려요. 보통 이런 사람들은 작은 스타트업에서 만나는데, 공동창업자(co-founder)가 엔지니어에게 “페이스북 광고(Facebook ads) 어떻게 되는지 알아봐”라고 그냥 시키는 그런 곳이에요.
text_zh: 我觉得最牛的用户获取(user acquisition)高手其实都是工程师，他们根本不需要什么营销技术专家，因为工具都是自己搭建的。付费推广(paid campaign)怎么跑他们门儿清，什么都能自己搞定。你通常能在小创业公司见到这种大神，就是联合创始人跟工程师说一句："嘿，你去研究研究Facebook广告怎么玩。"
text_es: Creo que la gente más extraordinaria en adquisición de usuarios son los ingenieros, y no necesitan un tecnólogo de marketing porque ellos mismos configuran las herramientas. Saben cómo funcionan las campañas pagadas y simplemente lo hacen todo. Y normalmente encuentras a estos genios en startups pequeñas donde el cofundador le dice al ingeniero: "Oye, averigua cómo funcionan los anuncios de Facebook."
context: Lenny asks about the relationship between MarTech people and paid growth specialists. Austin explains that the most effective user acquisition professionals are those with engineering backgrounds who can handle both the technical setup and campaign management themselves. However, he notes this is rare and typically occurs at small startups where engineers are forced to learn marketing out of necessity when founders tell them to "figure out" advertising platforms.
vocabulary_highlights: superhuman, super humans
topics: Growth & Marketing, Starting a Company, Career Development

speaker: Ayo Omojola
text: My perspective is that, and I think this is a, people don't like this kind of answer. But the thing Cash App did right was like 10 things, not one. There were like 10 things that actually best in class, like insane talent density, insane focus, very strong at fraud, a lot of the way Brian, and Dustin, and Jesse, and Dangi tried to organize the amount... Like you know, with Jack's support was just really firewalled from the rest of the square, the hero customer was the consumer, not the merchants, so it was like literally in 100% of the trade offs the consumer's needs came first.
text_ko: 제 관점엔, 사람들이 이런 답을 별로 좋아하진 않아요. 그런데 Cash App이 잘한 건 한 가지가 아니라 열 가지쯤 됐어요. 인재 밀도(talent density)가 압도적이었고, 집중력도 대단했고, 사기 방지(fraud)에 매우 강했고, Brian·Dustin·Jesse·Dangi가 조직을 짜는 방식과 잭(Jack)의 지원 덕분에 스퀘어(Square)의 다른 부분과는 사실상 완전히 분리돼 있었어요. 영웅 고객(hero customer)이 소비자였기 때문에, 실제로 모든 트레이드오프(trade-offs)에서 항상 소비자의 필요를 최우선으로 뒀어요.
text_zh: 我的看法是，虽然可能大家不太爱听这种答案，但Cash App之所以成功，不是因为一个因素，而是有十来个方面都做得特别到位。比如说人才密度(talent density)极高，专注度超强，风控做得特别厉害，还有Brian、Dustin、Jesse、Dangi他们几个人在Jack的支持下，把这块业务和Square其他部分完全隔离开来运营。最关键的是，他们把消费者当作核心用户，不是商家，所以基本上所有的决策权衡都是消费者需求优先。
text_es: Mi punto de vista es que, y creo que esto es algo que a la gente no le gusta escuchar como respuesta. Pero lo que Cash App hizo bien no fue una sola cosa, sino como 10 cosas. Fueron como 10 cosas que realmente estaban a nivel de excelencia, como una densidad de talento impresionante, un enfoque increíble, muy sólidos en temas de fraude, mucho de la forma en que Brian, y Dustin, y Jesse, y Dangi trataron de organizar todo... Ya sabes, con el apoyo de Jack, estaba realmente aislado del resto de Square, el cliente héroe era el consumidor, no los comerciantes, entonces literalmente en el 100% de las decisiones las necesidades del consumidor iban primero.
context: Lenny asks Ayo what Cash App did most right to launch successfully in the consumer space and scale to 50+ million monthly actives. Ayo explains that people often want to identify one key factor for success, but Cash App's achievement came from excelling at multiple dimensions simultaneously. He emphasizes that they maintained insane talent density, laser focus, fraud expertise, and most importantly, they were completely firewalled from Square's merchant business so consumer needs always came first in every trade-off decision.
vocabulary_highlights: insane talent density, firewalled from, hero customer, trade offs
topics: Product Management, Strategy & Planning, Leadership & Management

speaker: Ayo Omojola
text: Being different is not enough, because it's very easy to build a thing that's different from what exists today, because you just have to look at what exists today and build something else. Being better is not enough, because it's also easy to say, 'Hey, I'm going to make this thing better, and just charge you more money for it.' It has to be better than what exists today in a way that matters to the end user, and for us for a long time it was when someone says, 'Hey, why are you betting on Venmo?' I'd be like, 'Try and send me a dollar that I can use now,' and there was only one app you could do it with.
text_ko: 다르다고 되는 건 아니에요. 오늘 있는 것들과 그냥 다르게 만드는 건 너무 쉬워서, 지금 있는 걸 보고 ‘그거랑은 다른 걸 만들자’ 하면 되니까요. 더 나은 것도 충분하지 않아요. ‘이걸 더 좋게 만들어서 그냥 더 비싸게 팔면 되지’라고 말하는 건 역시 쉬운 일이니까요. 중요한 건 지금 있는 것들보다 나은데, 그 ‘나음’이 최종 사용자(end user)에게 실제로 의미가 있어야 한다는 거예요. 우리에게 오랫동안 기준이 됐던 건, 누군가가 “왜 Venmo에 베팅하냐?”고 물으면 제가 “지금 당장 내가 쓸 수 있는 1달러를 나한테 보내봐”라고 했을 때, 그걸 보낼 수 있는 앱이 딱 하나뿐이었어요.
text_zh: 光是不一样还不够，因为做个跟现在市面上不同的东西太容易了，你只要看看现在有什么，然后做点别的就行了。光是更好也不够，因为谁都可以说"嘿，我要把这个做得更好，然后多收你点钱"。关键是要比现有的产品好，而且这个"好"得对终端用户有意义。对我们来说，很长时间里，当有人问"你们为什么看好Venmo？"我就会说，"你试试给我转一块钱，让我现在就能用"，当时只有一个app能做到这点。
text_es: Ser diferente no es suficiente, porque es súper fácil crear algo que sea diferente a lo que ya existe - nada más tienes que ver qué hay ahora y hacer otra cosa. Ser mejor tampoco basta, porque también es fácil decir "Oye, voy a mejorar esto y te voy a cobrar más por ello." Tiene que ser mejor que lo que existe hoy, pero de una manera que realmente le importe al usuario final. Para nosotros, por mucho tiempo, cuando alguien nos decía "¿Por qué están apostando por Venmo?", yo les contestaba "A ver, mándame un dólar que pueda usar ahorita mismo" - y solo había una app con la que lo podías hacer.
context: Ayo is explaining Cash App's differentiation strategy and what made it successful against competitors like Venmo. He's describing how the team focused on being both different AND better in ways that truly mattered to users. Cash App's key differentiator was instant money transfer - when you received money, you could use it immediately rather than waiting for processing. This gave them a clear, demonstrable advantage that users could experience firsthand when comparing apps.
vocabulary_highlights: betting on, cut through the clutter
topics: Product Management, Strategy & Planning, Growth & Marketing

speaker: Ayo Omojola
text: I think when you are in a large organization, trying to do a actually new thing, I think small teams are better than big ones, period. And forcing the teams to be like super, sort of thoughtful about hitting milestones and actually adding value, because there's this thing people say about like, 'Hey, the startup within a startup, everything's fake.' And the reason I think it's fake is because when you're a startup you actually worry about paying the people who work for you, and when you aren't inside of a company you just don't.
text_ko: 제가 보기엔 큰 조직 안에서 진짜 새로운 걸 하려면 소규모 팀이 대규모 팀보다 무조건 더 좋아요. 그리고 팀들이 마일스톤(milestones)을 지키고 실제로 가치(value)를 만들어내는 것에 대해 철저히, 진지하게 고민하게끔 해야 해요. 사람들이 '스타트업 안의 스타트업(startup within a startup)은 다 가짜다'고 하는데, 제가 그걸 가짜라고 보는 이유는 진짜 스타트업은 같이 일하는 사람들의 급여를 실제로 걱정하게 되지만 회사 안에 있으면 그런 걱정을 안 하게 되거든요.
text_zh: 我觉得在大公司里想搞点真正创新的东西，小团队绝对比大团队好使，这没什么好争的。而且得逼着这些团队特别用心地去达成里程碑，真正创造价值，因为经常有人说什么"公司内部的创业团队啊，都是假的"。我觉得之所以假，是因为真正的创业公司你得操心给员工发工资的事儿，但在大公司内部你根本不用担心这个。
text_es: Creo que cuando estás en una organización grande, tratando de hacer algo realmente nuevo, los equipos pequeños funcionan mejor que los grandes, punto. Y hay que obligar a los equipos a ser súper conscientes de cumplir objetivos y realmente agregar valor, porque existe esa cosa que dice la gente de "oye, la startup dentro de la startup, todo es falso." Y creo que es falso porque cuando eres una startup de verdad te preocupas por pagarle a la gente que trabaja contigo, y cuando estás dentro de una empresa grande simplemente no te preocupas por eso.
context: Lenny asks Ayo what Square/Block did right as a product company that he brings to his current role. Ayo explains his philosophy about building new products within large organizations. He argues that small teams are more effective because they maintain the existential pressure that real startups face. In true startups, founders worry about meeting payroll, but internal teams don't have that same urgency, which can lead to resource bloat without corresponding results.
vocabulary_highlights: startup within a startup, existential fear
topics: Starting a Company, Leadership & Management, Strategy & Planning

speaker: Ayo Omojola
text: When you're hiring you pick the people, but they pick when. So you're actually like, there's these people... There are many, many people on the team who, the time between when I first met them and the time when they joined the team was like months. There was one person who was like, a year and a half almost. And so the way that I operationalize that is, I'm meeting people all the time, and I am just like, 'Hey,' like, if I meet somebody I want to work with, I'm like, 'Hey, how can I add value to your life so you will consider me somebody who you would like to work with one day, so that when the time comes and there's an opportunity for us to work together, you're actually open to it, as opposed to just some guy that you met on a Zoom one time.'
text_ko: 채용할 때는 우리가 사람을 고르지만, 그들이 언제 올지는 결국 그들이 정해요. 사실 팀에 합류하기까지 처음 만난 순간부터 실제로 합류할 때까지 몇 달이 걸리는 사람이 정말 많아요. 어떤 사람은 거의 1년 반이나 걸렸어요. 그래서 저는 그걸 이렇게 실무적으로 풀어요. 계속 사람들을 만나고, 같이 일하고 싶은 사람을 만나면 '안녕하세요' 하고 다가가서 '제가 어떻게 하면 당신 삶에 가치를 더해서 언젠가 함께 일할 사람으로 저를 생각해주실 수 있을까요? 그러면 기회가 왔을 때 진짜 열려 계시지, 줌(Zoom)에서 한 번 만난 사람으로만 남지 않잖아요'라고 말해요.
text_zh: 招人的时候是这样的，你可以挑人，但什么时候加入是他们说了算。所以实际上就是，有很多团队成员，从我第一次见到他们，到他们真正加入团队，中间隔了好几个月。有一个人差不多等了一年半才来。所以我的做法就是，我会一直去认识各种人，然后就想着，如果遇到想合作的人，我就会想"我怎么能给你的生活带来价值，让你觉得我是个值得合作的人，这样以后有机会一起工作的时候，你会愿意考虑，而不是把我当成只是在Zoom上见过一面的路人甲。"
text_es: Cuando contratas, tú eliges a las personas, pero ellas eligen cuándo. O sea, realmente es como... hay muchísima gente en el equipo donde el tiempo entre que los conocí por primera vez y cuando se unieron al equipo fue de meses. Hubo una persona que tardó como año y medio, casi. Entonces la forma en que yo operacionalizo eso es que estoy conociendo gente todo el tiempo, y simplemente es como, "Oye," o sea, si conozco a alguien con quien quiero trabajar, le digo, "Oye, ¿cómo puedo aportarte valor a tu vida para que me consideres alguien con quien te gustaría trabajar algún día? Para que cuando llegue el momento y haya una oportunidad de trabajar juntos, realmente estés abierto a ello, en lugar de ser simplemente un tipo que conociste una vez por Zoom."
context: Lenny asks Ayo about his hiring and team-building philosophies beyond his preference for hiring founders. Ayo explains his long-term approach to talent acquisition - recognizing that while he can choose who to pursue, candidates control the timing of when they're ready to join. He invests in relationships by actively helping people achieve their current goals, positioning himself as someone they'd want to work with when the right opportunity arises, rather than just another recruiter who reached out once.
vocabulary_highlights: operationalize that, add value to your life

speaker: Ayo Omojola
text: My biggest thing, and I say this all the time, is that everybody wants something. And most of the time it's not something you have to give, or you can connect them to. But, if it is something that you have to give, or you can connect them to, it's criminal not to, actually. It's like, imagine you, like just imagine you having a conversation with somebody, and that person, knowing that you want something, having it, there's no cost enough to give it to you, and they just don't do it. How crazy is that?
text_ko: 내가 항상 말하는 가장 중요한 점은, 모든 사람이 뭔가를 원한다는 거예요. 그리고 대부분의 경우 그게 당신이 줄 수 있는 것이거나 연결해줄 수 있는 것이 아닐 때가 많아요. 하지만 만약 당신이 줄 수 있는 것이거나 연결해줄 수 있는 것이라면, 그걸 안 해주는 건 정말 잘못된 거예요. 상상해보세요, 누군가와 대화하고 있는데 그 사람이 당신이 원하는 걸 알고 있고, 그걸 줄 비용이 전혀 없는데도 그냥 안 해주는 거예요. 그게 얼마나 미친 짓인가요?
text_zh: 我最常说的一个观点就是，每个人都有需求对吧。大部分时候呢，可能不是你能提供的，或者你也帮不上忙。但是，如果真的是你能给的，或者你能牵个线搭个桥的，那不帮忙就真的说不过去了。你想想啊，就好比你跟别人聊天，对方明明知道你想要什么，他也有这个资源，给你也不费什么事儿，结果他就是不给你。这不是挺奇葩的吗？
text_es: Mi punto principal, y lo digo siempre, es que todo el mundo quiere algo. Y la mayoría de las veces no es algo que tú tengas para ofrecer, o que puedas conectarlos con alguien que lo tenga. Pero, si resulta que sí es algo que tú puedes dar, o puedes conectarlos, es una locura no hacerlo, en serio. Es como, imagínate que estás hablando con alguien, y esa persona, sabiendo que tú quieres algo, lo tiene, no le cuesta nada dártelo, y simplemente no lo hace. ¿Qué tan absurdo es eso?
context: Ayo continues explaining his networking and relationship-building philosophy. He describes his core belief that everyone wants something, and when you can help provide what someone needs at little cost to yourself, it's morally wrong not to help them. He uses this principle to build long-term professional relationships by actively connecting people to opportunities, introductions, or resources they need, which eventually comes back to benefit him through stronger networks and goodwill.
vocabulary_highlights: it's criminal not to, no cost enough to give it to you

speaker: Ayo Omojola
text: It's not that you have to do everything yourself, it's that the person who you trust in the execution role, they have to become the expert. They have to be like, they can't stop until they hit the end. And, I don't know. I think in all these places where strong, ambitious people are trying big things, so much value is lost when the person in the execution role isn't really in command of all the details, and is like... So I think the reality's like, to do ambitious things you have to work with people, I can't do everything myself and I know that. The real lesson there is, it's not like I have to, just, somebody has to.
text_ko: 제가 다 직접 해야 하는 건 아니에요. 중요한 건 실행 담당자(execution role)를 믿는다면 그 사람이 전문가가 돼야 한다는 거예요. 그 사람은 끝을 볼 때까지 멈출 수 없어야 해요. 음… 야심 있는 사람들이 큰 목표에 도전하는 곳에서는 실행을 맡은 사람이 모든 디테일을 완전히 파악하고 있지 못하면 엄청난 가치가 사라져요. 그래서 현실은, 야심찬 일을 하려면 사람들과 함께 일해야 하고 저 혼자 다 할 수는 없다는 거예요. 진짜 교훈은 '내가 다 해야 한다'가 아니라 '누군가는 해야 한다'는 거예요.
text_zh: 不是说你得什么事儿都自己干，而是你信任的那个负责执行的人，他必须得成为这方面的专家。他得有那种不达目的不罢休的劲头。我觉得吧，在那些有野心的人想干大事的地方，如果负责执行的人对各种细节都不够了解，掌控不了全局，那真的会损失很多价值。所以现实就是，要想干成大事，你肯定得和别人合作，我也知道我不可能什么都自己来。真正的道理是，不是非得我来，但总得有人能扛起这个责任。
text_es: No es que tengas que hacer todo tú solo, sino que la persona en quien confías para la ejecución tiene que convertirse en el experto. Tiene que estar en modo de "no paro hasta llegar al final". Y no sé... Creo que en todos estos lugares donde gente ambiciosa y fuerte está intentando cosas grandes, se pierde muchísimo valor cuando la persona a cargo de la ejecución no domina realmente todos los detalles, y está como que... Entonces pienso que la realidad es que para hacer cosas ambiciosas tienes que trabajar con gente, no puedo hacerlo todo yo solo y lo sé. La verdadera lección ahí es que no es que yo tenga que hacerlo, simplemente alguien lo tiene que hacer.
context: Lenny asks Ayo to clarify his philosophy about 'going deep' on problems after hearing his story about personally visiting card manufacturing facilities for the Cash Card. Ayo explains that he doesn't believe leaders must personally do everything, but rather that someone in the execution role must become the true expert and own all the details. He argues that in ambitious projects, massive value is lost when executors aren't in complete command of the specifics, and leaders must ensure someone on the team has that deep expertise.
vocabulary_highlights: can't stop until they hit the end, in command of all the details
topics: Leadership & Management, Strategy & Planning, Learning & Growth

speaker: Bangaly Kaba
speaker_expertise: Growth Strategy, User Experience, Product Management
text: I found this framework travels with me. It's got these five components to it, vision, skills, incentives, resources, action plan, and you need all of those to have change. And then within those buckets you've got to figure out what are the right levers that you need to pull? What are the things that are missing?
text_ko: 저와 늘 함께하는 프레임워크(framework)이에요. 다섯 가지 요소로 구성돼 있는데, 비전(vision), 역량(skills), 인센티브(incentives), 자원(resources), 실행 계획(action plan)이에요. 변화를 만들려면 이 모든 요소가 필요해요. 그리고 각 요소 안에서 어떤 지렛대(levers)를 당겨야 할지, 어떤 부분이 빠져 있는지 찾아내야 해요.
text_zh: 我发现这个框架(framework)特别实用，走到哪都能用。它有五个要素：愿景、技能、激励机制、资源，还有行动计划。想要推动变革，这五样缺一不可。然后在每个板块里，你得琢磨哪些是关键抓手，哪些地方还有缺口。
text_es: He descubierto que este marco de trabajo me acompaña a donde vaya. Tiene cinco componentes: visión, habilidades, incentivos, recursos, y plan de acción, y necesitas todos esos elementos para lograr el cambio. Y luego, dentro de cada una de esas áreas, tienes que identificar cuáles son las palancas correctas que debes activar. ¿Qué es lo que te está faltando?
context: Lenny introduces Bangaly as someone who has had a lot of impact on different cultures at various tech companies. Bangaly explains his framework for managing complex change, which he uses when joining new teams or trying to transform organizational culture. The framework consists of five essential components that must all be present for successful change: vision, skills, incentives, resources, and action plan. When any component is missing, it leads to different problems like confusion, anxiety, or false starts.
vocabulary_highlights: travels with me, levers that you need to pull

speaker: Bangaly Kaba
speaker_expertise: Growth Strategy, User Experience, Product Management
text: What I call the anti-pattern of what we want to do. Someone says, "Hey, you know what? This would be great to build." And you go pull data to go justify why that would be great to build. Call that identify, justify, execute. First you have to really understand from first principles what is actually going on. So understand, identify, execute.
text_ko: 제가 말하는 '우리가 하려는 일의 안티패턴(anti-pattern)'이 있어요. 누군가 '야, 이거 만들면 좋겠다' 그러면 곧바로 그걸 만들면 좋다는 걸 증명하려고 데이터를 끌어와 정당화(justify)해요. 그걸 identify, justify, execute(identify, justify, execute)라고 부르죠. 그런데 먼저 근본 원리(first principles)부터 출발해서 진짜 무슨 일이 일어나고 있는지 제대로 이해(understand)해야 해요. 그래서 순서는 이해(understand), 식별(identify), 실행(execute)이에요.
text_zh: 我把这叫做我们要做的事情的反面典型。有人说："嘿，你知道吗？做这个东西肯定很棒。" 然后你就去找数据来证明为什么做这个东西很棒。我把这叫做识别、论证、执行。但实际上你得先从根本原理真正搞明白到底是怎么回事。所以应该是理解、识别、执行。
text_es: A esto le llamo el anti-patrón de lo que queremos hacer. Alguien dice, "Oye, ¿sabes qué? Esto estaría genial construirlo." Y vas y buscas datos para justificar por qué sería genial construirlo. A eso le llamo identificar, justificar, ejecutar. Pero primero tienes que entender realmente desde los principios básicos qué está pasando en realidad. O sea, entender, identificar, ejecutar.
context: Lenny asks about Bangaly's concept of 'understand work' - spending intentional time understanding problems before building solutions. Bangaly explains that most teams fall into a dangerous pattern he calls 'identify, justify, execute' where they identify something to build, then find data to justify it, then spend enormous time building it only to see flat metrics. He advocates for 'understand, identify, execute' instead, where teams must first deeply understand the problem space from first principles before identifying solutions.
vocabulary_highlights: anti-pattern, from first principles

speaker: Bangaly Kaba
speaker_expertise: Growth Strategy, User Experience, Product Management
text: There's impact that you're really trying to drop and the impact is only achievable by looking at set of variables related to the environment, the set of variables related to your skills.
