text_ko: 진짜로 만들고 싶은 임팩트는 환경(environment)과 역량(skills) 쪽의 여러 변수(variables)를 모두 살펴봐야만 만들어낼 수 있어요.
text_zh: 你想要产生的影响力，只有通过分析两套变量才能实现——一套是环境相关的变量，另一套是你自身能力相关的变量。
text_es: Hay un impacto que realmente estás tratando de lograr, y ese impacto solo se puede alcanzar si analizas las variables del entorno y las variables relacionadas con tus habilidades.
context: Lenny asks about Bangaly's legendary blog post 'How to Choose Where to Work and What to Work On' and his framework for career decisions. Bangaly explains that career success should be optimized around impact rather than compensation or other factors. His framework states that impact is the product of two main variable sets: environmental factors (like your manager, resources, scope) and your personal skills. Impact is the key metric because other benefits like compensation and scope naturally follow from having high impact.
vocabulary_highlights: trying to drop

speaker: Bangaly Kaba
speaker_expertise: Growth Strategy, User Experience, Product Management
text: The environment was the one to me, that I think is most people overlook and I overlooked when I was first thinking about this. Environment in this case, I think I kind of discreetly named a few things. One is your manager, then there's the resources. So what kind of team do you have? Is your team staffed appropriately?
text_ko: 저한테 환경(environment)은 사람들이 가장 놓치기 쉬운 부분 같아요. 저도 처음엔 놓쳤고요. 여기서 말하는 환경은 제가 몇 가지를 꼽은 건데, 하나는 매니저(manager)고, 또 하나는 리소스(resources)예요. 결국 어떤 팀을 갖고 있느냐, 팀에 필요한 인력이 적절히 배치돼 있느냐가 핵심이죠.
text_zh: 环境这个因素对我来说，我觉得大多数人都会忽视，我最开始考虑这个问题的时候也忽视了。说到环境，我觉得其实包含几个方面。一个是你的上级领导，还有就是资源配置。比如说你的团队怎么样？人员配备到位了吗？
text_es: El entorno era lo que para mí, creo que la mayoría de la gente pasa por alto y yo también lo pasé por alto cuando empecé a pensar en esto. El entorno en este caso, creo que mencioné discretamente algunas cosas. Una es tu jefe, luego están los recursos. Entonces, ¿qué tipo de equipo tienes? ¿Tu equipo tiene el personal adecuado?
context: Lenny asks Bangaly to elaborate on the two elements of his impact equation: environment and skills. Bangaly explains that environment is the factor most people overlook when evaluating their career situation. He breaks down environment into six specific components: your manager, resources (team and budget), scope of responsibility, team skills, compensation, and company culture. He emphasizes that people often focus only on developing their skills while ignoring environmental factors that could be limiting their impact.
vocabulary_highlights: discreetly named

speaker: Bangaly Kaba
speaker_expertise: Growth Strategy, User Experience, Product Management
text: I tell them, it's actually better to have a stable of mentors. You want to have three or four. And ideally, what you do is you meet with each one of them once a month on a different Friday of the month. And so you might have three or four people on every Friday you're meeting with someone different.
text_ko: 저는 보통 이렇게 말해요: 멘토를 여러 명 두는 게 사실 더 좋아요. 세 명에서 네 명 정도면 좋아요. 이상적으로는 각 멘토를 매달 한 번씩, 달의 서로 다른 금요일에 만나는 거예요. 그러면 세네 명이면 매주 금요일마다 다른 멘토와 만나게 되는 셈이죠.
text_zh: 我跟他们说，其实最好是有一批导师，不要只找一个。你最好找三四个人。理想的做法是，每个月的不同周五分别跟他们见面。这样你可能有三四个人，每个周五都能跟不同的人聊聊。
text_es: Les digo que en realidad es mejor tener un grupo de mentores. Lo ideal es tener tres o cuatro. Y lo que haces es reunirte con cada uno una vez al mes, un viernes diferente cada vez. Entonces puedes tener tres o cuatro personas y cada viernes te reúnes con alguien distinto.
context: Lenny asks about Bangaly's advice for skill development, particularly around finding mentors. Bangaly challenges the traditional approach of having one mentor, instead recommending what he calls a 'stable of mentors' - three to four different mentors that you meet with on rotating Fridays each month. This approach ensures consistent mentorship availability and diverse perspectives, as opposed to relying on a single mentor who might be unavailable for extended periods.
vocabulary_highlights: stable of mentors

speaker: Bangaly Kaba
speaker_expertise: Growth Strategy, User Experience, Product Management
text: What I found is a couple things. One is when your team does not fully understand a problem space, the balance of work tends to be higher. I think when I started at YouTube we were doing 60% execution, 40% understand work. Right. And over time, as we understand more and more, the mix shifts.
text_ko: 제가 발견한 건 몇 가지예요. 하나는, 팀이 문제 영역(problem space)을 완전히 이해하지 못하면 일의 비중이 실행(execution) 쪽으로 더 높아지는 경향이 있다는 거예요. 제가 유튜브에 처음 들어갔을 때는 실행(execution)이 60%, 이해 작업(understand work)이 40%였던 것 같아요. 시간이 지나면서 더 많이 이해하게 되면 그 비율이 바뀌어요.
text_zh: 我发现了几个情况。一个是当你的团队对问题领域理解不够深的时候，工作量往往会更大。我觉得我刚到YouTube的时候，我们大概是60%在执行，40%在做理解性的工作。对吧。然后随着时间推移，我们理解得越来越多，这个比例就开始变化了。
text_es: Lo que me di cuenta es de un par de cosas. Una es que cuando tu equipo no entiende completamente un área problemática, la carga de trabajo tiende a ser mayor. Creo que cuando empecé en YouTube estábamos haciendo 60% ejecución, 40% trabajo de entendimiento. ¿No? Y con el tiempo, conforme vamos entendiendo más y más, la mezcla va cambiando.
context: Lenny asks how to operationalize 'understand work' - the intentional time spent understanding problems before building solutions. Bangaly explains that the ratio of understand work to execution depends on how well the team understands their problem space. When he started at YouTube, his team spent 40% of their time on understand work because they lacked deep knowledge of their domain. As understanding increased, they shifted to 80-85% execution and only 15-20% understand work, demonstrating how this investment pays off with higher velocity over time.
vocabulary_highlights: balance of work tends to be higher, the mix shifts

speaker: Barbra Gago
text: When you're building a category, you need to make sure that there is a category that's validated by analysts and directory sites and things like that. But also, you want to have a lot of traction in terms of thought leadership like why is this the category? What are the unique value propositions of this particular thing? What are the pain points it solves? And then of course, getting a lot of content around because when you're generating a new category, you're also needing to educate buyers that there is a category that they can now budget for and why they should allocate budget for that.
text_ko: 카테고리(category)를 만들 때는 애널리스트(analysts)나 디렉터리 사이트(directory sites) 같은 곳에서 검증된 카테고리가 있는지 확인해야 해요. 동시에 ‘왜 이게 카테고리인가’에 대한 답을 제시할 수 있는 사고 리더십(thought leadership) 측면에서 충분한 트랙션(traction)이 있어야 하고, 이게 제공하는 고유한 가치 제안(unique value propositions)은 무엇인지, 어떤 고충(pain points)을 해결하는지도 분명히 해야 해요. 그리고 당연히 관련 콘텐츠를 많이 만들어야 해요. 새로운 카테고리를 만들면 구매자(buyers)들에게 그 카테고리가 존재한다는 것과 왜 그걸 위해 예산(budget)을 배정해야 하는지 교육해야 하니까요.
text_zh: 当你在打造一个新品类的时候，你得确保这个品类能得到分析师和各种目录网站的认可。但同时呢，你也要在思想领导力(thought leadership)方面下功夫，比如说为什么会有这个品类？这个东西的独特价值主张(unique value propositions)是什么？它能解决哪些痛点？然后当然了，还要做大量的内容，因为你在创造一个全新品类的时候，其实也需要教育买家，让他们知道现在有这么个品类可以做预算了，以及为什么应该给这个品类分配预算。
text_es: Cuando estás creando una categoría, tienes que asegurarte de que sea una categoría validada por analistas y sitios de directorios y todo eso. Pero también necesitas tener mucha tracción en términos de liderazgo de pensamiento (thought leadership), o sea, ¿por qué esta es LA categoría? ¿Cuáles son las propuestas de valor únicas de esto en particular? ¿Qué puntos de dolor resuelve? Y después, claro, generar un montón de contenido porque cuando estás creando una nueva categoría, también necesitas educar a los compradores de que existe una categoría para la cual ya pueden presupuestar y por qué deberían asignar presupuesto para eso.
context: Lenny asks Barbra about the tactical process of category creation - what steps companies need to take when trying to establish a new product category. Barbra explains that building a new product category requires validation from industry analysts like Gartner and directory sites like G2 Crowd, but also demands significant thought leadership and content marketing efforts. She emphasizes that when creating a new category, you're not just marketing a product but educating the entire market about why this category should exist and deserve budget allocation.
vocabulary_highlights: traction in terms of thought leadership, unique value propositions, allocate budget for

speaker: Barbra Gago
text: We tried several things. One of the main things that we zeroed in on was recruiting optimization platform, and it was really like we are doing that. We're helping companies really structure the process, identify where they have gaps, where people are falling through the cracks, where they're flying through the process and really tweak and iterate it and improve it.
text_ko: 저희가 여러 가지를 시도해 봤어요. 그중에 집중한 핵심 중 하나가 채용 최적화 플랫폼(recruiting optimization platform)이었고, 사실 말 그대로 그걸 실행하고 있어요. 기업들이 채용 프로세스를 체계화하고 어디에 허점이 있는지, 지원자가 어디서 빠져나가는지, 어떤 단계는 너무 빨리 지나가는지 등을 찾아내 세부적으로 조정하고 반복해서 개선할 수 있도록 도와드려요.
text_zh: 我们试了好多种做法。其中一个重点就是招聘优化平台(recruiting optimization platform)，这个确实是我们在做的事儿。我们帮公司把整个流程梳理清楚，找出哪儿有漏洞，哪些人才被漏掉了，哪些环节走得太快，然后不断地调整优化，让整个招聘流程越来越好。
text_es: Probamos varias cosas. Una de las principales en las que nos enfocamos fue una plataforma de optimización de reclutamiento, y era exactamente lo que estábamos haciendo. Estamos ayudando a las empresas a estructurar bien el proceso, a identificar dónde tienen huecos, dónde se les están escapando candidatos, dónde la gente pasa muy rápido por el proceso, y realmente ajustarlo, ir mejorándolo paso a paso.
context: Lenny asks Barbra about Greenhouse's failed attempt at category creation. Barbra explains how they tried to move away from the negatively perceived ATS (Applicant Tracking System) category by creating a new category called 'recruiting optimization platform.' She describes how they positioned Greenhouse as helping companies optimize their recruiting processes by identifying inefficiencies and gaps in their hiring workflows, rather than just being another transactional applicant tracking system.
vocabulary_highlights: zeroed in on, falling through the cracks, flying through the process, tweak and iterate

speaker: Barbra Gago
text: So it didn't really make sense to continue to go against the grain of, no, we're going to be this new thing or we're going to call it this if everybody, even seeing the value and seeing the differentiation of our platform to others, still called it an ATS. We abandoned that process. But I think the main thing that we understood then was instead of spending the time and money to build a new category, we were going to spend the time and money to elevate the value of this category.
text_ko: 그래서 '우리가 이걸 완전히 새로운 것으로 만들겠다'거나 '이렇게 불러야겠다'며 억지로 밀고 가는 건 의미가 없겠다고 판단했어요. 사람들이 우리 플랫폼의 가치와 차별성은 알아봐도, 여전히 지원자 추적 시스템(applicant tracking system, ATS)이라고 부르는 경우가 많았거든요. 그래서 그 시도는 접었어요. 대신 그때 우리가 깨달은 핵심은, 새로운 카테고리를 만들기 위해 시간과 돈을 쓰기보다는 그 카테고리의 가치를 끌어올리는 데 시간과 자원을 쓰겠다는 거였어요.
text_zh: 所以继续跟大家对着干其实没什么意义，我们非要说自己是个全新的东西，非要给它起个新名字，但实际上大家都看得出我们平台的价值和跟其他家的差异化，可还是叫它ATS。我们就不再坚持那套了。但我觉得最主要的是，我们当时明白了，与其花时间和钱去打造一个新品类，不如把这些时间和钱用来提升这个品类的价值。
text_es: Entonces realmente no tenía sentido seguir yendo contra la corriente, diciendo "no, vamos a ser algo nuevo" o "lo vamos a llamar de otra forma" si todo el mundo, aun viendo el valor y la diferenciación de nuestra plataforma respecto a otras, seguía llamándolo un ATS. Abandonamos ese proceso. Pero creo que lo principal que entendimos entonces fue que en lugar de gastar el tiempo y el dinero en crear una nueva categoría, íbamos a invertir ese tiempo y dinero en elevar el valor de esta categoría.
context: Lenny is learning about when category creation fails and companies should pivot their approach. Barbra explains how Greenhouse ultimately abandoned their attempt to create the 'recruiting optimization platform' category because customers kept referring to their product as an ATS despite understanding its superior value. Instead of fighting market perception, they decided to elevate and transform the existing ATS category by making it more strategic and valuable to users.
vocabulary_highlights: go against the grain, abandoned that process, elevate the value

speaker: Barbra Gago
text: And so visual collaboration was our way of putting a nice bow around this thing that could then be an enterprise product that solves a lot of different problems for a lot of different use cases and different types of users. We started out selling and having a lot of users that were in product and in engineering and teams that were used to using whiteboards anyway and then needed to do it in a distributed way, but very quickly packaged different types of jobs for HR teams or marketing teams or design teams and pretty much anybody in the organization.
text_ko: 그래서 비주얼 협업(visual collaboration)은 이걸 깔끔하게 포장해 주는 방식이었고, 그게 결국 다양한 사용 사례(use cases)와 여러 유형의 사용자들이 겪는 여러 문제를 해결하는 엔터프라이즈 제품(enterprise product)이 되게 해줬어요. 처음에는 제품팀과 엔지니어링팀에서 일하는 분들, 원래부터 화이트보드를 쓰던 팀들이 주된 사용자였고 원격으로도 같은 작업을 해야 해서 쓰기 시작했어요. 그런데 생각보다 빨리 인사(HR)팀이나 마케팅팀, 디자인팀 같은 다른 직무용 패키지도 만들게 되었고, 결국 조직 내 거의 누구나 쓸 수 있는 도구가 되었어요.
text_zh: 所以可视化协作(visual collaboration)就是我们把这个东西包装得漂漂亮亮的方式，让它能成为一个企业级产品，解决各种不同用户在各种不同场景下的各种问题。我们一开始主要是卖给产品和工程团队的用户，这些团队本来就习惯用白板，现在需要远程协作的方式来做，但很快我们就针对HR团队、市场团队、设计团队包装出了不同类型的解决方案，基本上公司里任何部门都能用。
text_es: Y entonces la colaboración visual fue nuestra manera de darle el toque final a esto que luego podría convertirse en un producto empresarial que resolviera un montón de problemas diferentes para muchos casos de uso distintos y diferentes tipos de usuarios. Empezamos vendiendo y teniendo muchos usuarios que estaban en producto y en ingeniería, equipos que ya estaban acostumbrados a usar pizarras blancas (whiteboards) y que necesitaban hacerlo de forma distribuida, pero muy rápido empaquetamos diferentes tipos de trabajos para equipos de RR.HH. o equipos de marketing o equipos de diseño y prácticamente cualquier persona de la organización.
context: Lenny asks about how Miro successfully created the visual collaboration category when there wasn't existing budget for it. Barbra explains how 'visual collaboration' served as an umbrella term that unified Miro's diverse use cases across different teams and departments. She describes how they started with core users in product and engineering who already understood whiteboarding, then expanded to package the platform for various other teams throughout organizations.
vocabulary_highlights: putting a nice bow around, packaged different types of jobs

speaker: Barbra Gago
text: All of my best marketing and positioning literally comes from having a million conversations with customers and listening to how they solve problems and how our system helps them solve problems and what they're doing and how they talk about stuff. I think that's step one, is really understanding who those buyers are, how they talk about the product, what's the unique differentiator and selling points?
text_ko: 사실 제 최고의 마케팅과 포지셔닝(marketing and positioning)은 말 그대로 고객들과의 셀 수 없이 많은 대화에서 나와요. 그들이 문제를 어떻게 해결하는지, 우리 시스템이 그걸 어떻게 돕는지, 그들이 무슨 일을 하고 어떻게 말하는지를 귀 기울여 듣는 거예요. 제 생각엔 그게 첫 번째 단계예요 — 누가 그 구매자들(buyers)인지, 그들이 제품을 어떻게 표현하는지, 차별화 요소(unique differentiator)와 판매 포인트(selling points)가 뭔지 진짜로 이해하는 것 말이에요.
text_zh: 我所有最好的营销和定位策略，说白了就是跟客户聊了无数次，听他们怎么解决问题，我们的系统怎么帮他们解决问题，看他们平时都在做什么，听他们怎么表达这些事儿。我觉得第一步就是要真正搞清楚这些买家是谁，他们怎么谈论产品，我们的独特差异化(differentiator)和卖点(selling points)到底是什么？
text_es: Todo mi mejor marketing y posicionamiento viene literalmente de tener miles de conversaciones con clientes y escuchar cómo resuelven sus problemas, cómo nuestro sistema les ayuda a solucionarlos, qué están haciendo y cómo hablan de las cosas. Creo que ese es el primer paso: realmente entender quiénes son esos compradores, cómo hablan del producto, cuál es el diferenciador único y los puntos de venta clave.
context: Lenny asks for tactical advice about the category creation process for founders who want to explore this approach. Barbra emphasizes that successful marketing and positioning starts with extensive customer research and understanding exactly how customers describe their problems and solutions. She stresses that the foundation of category creation is deeply understanding buyer language, pain points, and how they naturally talk about the product's value proposition.
vocabulary_highlights: having a million conversations, unique differentiator

speaker: Barbra Gago
text: I almost didn't join because it was called RealtimeBoard. Honestly, I was like, 'Oh my, god. This is so literal.' While I was walking the dogs with my husband, I'm like, 'Am I really going to join a company called RealtimeBoard? Can this be a big company with that name?' I was really concerned about it and ultimately, I spent more time with the leaders there and I was like, 'Okay, I think they'll be open to changing the name.'
text_ko: RealtimeBoard라는 이름 때문에 거의 합류 안 할 뻔했어요. 솔직히 '세상에, 이름이 너무 문자 그대로네' 싶었거든요. 남편이랑 강아지 데리고 산책하면서도 '진짜 RealtimeBoard라는 회사에 들어갈까? 그런 이름으로 큰 회사가 될 수 있을까?' 하고 계속 고민했어요. 정말 걱정됐는데, 결국 거기 리더분들이랑 시간을 더 보내보니 '아, 이름 바꾸는 것에 대해 열려 있겠구나' 싶더라고요.
text_zh: 我当时差点没加入，因为公司叫RealtimeBoard。说实话，我当时想，"天哪，这名字也太直白了吧。" 我和老公遛狗的时候还在想，"我真的要加入一家叫RealtimeBoard的公司吗？就这个名字，能做成大公司吗？" 我真的很担心这个问题，后来跟那边的领导们接触多了，我想，"好吧，他们应该会愿意改名字的。"
text_es: Por poco no me uno porque se llamaba RealtimeBoard. En serio, yo pensaba 'Ay, Dios mío. Qué nombre tan literal.' Mientras paseaba a los perros con mi marido, le decía '¿De verdad me voy a meter a una empresa que se llama RealtimeBoard? ¿Puede ser una empresa grande con ese nombre?' Me preocupaba mucho el tema y al final, pasé más tiempo con los líderes de allá y dije 'Bueno, creo que van a estar abiertos a cambiar el nombre.'
context: Lenny asks about how to know when it's time to rebrand a product. Barbra shares her personal experience of nearly rejecting the Miro opportunity because of concerns about the original name 'RealtimeBoard.' She explains how the overly literal and descriptive name made her question whether the company could scale to become a major enterprise player, and how she made the potential rebrand a condition of joining the company.
vocabulary_highlights: so literal, be open to changing

speaker: Barbra Gago
text: The best way to incorporate your brand and how people are interacting with people that you are selling to, customers or whoever, partners, is to have those values incorporated because then it's every touchpoint isn't something that you have to train people, okay, these are all the touch points and this is how the brand needs to manifest. It already will because it's part of the DNA of the company.
text_ko: 브랜드(brand)와 고객이나 파트너 같은 판매 대상과의 상호작용을 제대로 녹여내는 가장 좋은 방법은 그 가치를 조직에 내재화하는 거예요. 그래야 매번 각 터치포인트(touchpoint)마다 사람들을 따로 교육하면서 “여기는 이렇게 해야 해요”라고 일일이 설명할 필요가 없어요. 브랜드가 어떻게 표현(manifest)되어야 하는지는 이미 회사 DNA(company DNA)에 배어 있어서 자연스럽게 드러나거든요.
text_zh: 要让品牌真正融入到你和客户、合作伙伴这些人的互动中，最好的办法就是把这些价值观真正植入进去。这样一来，每个接触点(touchpoint)都不用你去特意培训员工说"这些是接触点，品牌要这样体现"，因为这已经成了公司的DNA，自然而然就会体现出来。
text_es: La mejor manera de integrar tu marca y cómo la gente interactúa con las personas a las que les vendes - clientes, socios, quien sea - es tener esos valores ya incorporados. Porque así, cada punto de contacto (touchpoint) no es algo que tengas que andar enseñando a la gente: "mira, estos son todos los puntos de contacto y así es como la marca se tiene que manifestar." Ya va a salir natural porque forma parte del ADN de la empresa.
context: Lenny asks for examples of how company values can inform brand decisions and customer interactions. Barbra explains her philosophy that the strongest brands integrate company values so deeply into their DNA that brand expression becomes automatic across all customer touchpoints. She argues that when values are truly embedded in company culture, employees naturally embody the brand without extensive training because the values guide their authentic behavior.
vocabulary_highlights: every touchpoint, brand needs to manifest, part of the DNA

speaker: Ben Horowitz
speaker_expertise: Venture Capital, Product Management, Company Building
text: The psychological muscle you have to build to be a great leader is to be able to click in the abyss and go, 'Okay, that way's slightly better. We're going to go that way. If everybody agrees with the decision, then you didn't add any value because they would've done that without you.' So the only value you ever add is when you make a decision that most people don't like.
text_ko: 훌륭한 리더가 되려면 심리적 근육(psychological muscle)을 길러야 해요. 깊은 불확실성 속에서도 딱 결정을 내려서 “음, 저쪽이 조금 더 낫네요. 그쪽으로 가겠습니다”라고 말할 수 있어야 해요. 만약 모두가 그 결정에 동의했다면 당신은 아무런 가치를 더한 게 아니에요—그 사람들이 당신 없이도 그렇게 했을 테니까요. 그래서 리더로서 진짜 가치를 만드는 건 대부분의 사람들이 좋아하지 않는 결정을 내릴 때뿐이에요.
text_zh: 要成为优秀领导者，你得练就一种心理素质——就是在一片迷茫中还能拍板："好，那个方向稍微好一点，咱们就往那边走。"如果所有人都同意你的决定，那说明你其实没创造什么价值，因为没有你他们也会这么做。所以你真正的价值就体现在——当你做出大多数人都不太认同的决定时。
text_es: El músculo psicológico que tienes que desarrollar para ser un gran líder es poder quedarte ahí en el abismo y decir: "Bueno, por ahí se ve un poquito mejor. Vamos por ese lado." Si todo el mundo está de acuerdo con tu decisión, entonces no aportaste nada porque lo habrían hecho sin ti. Así que el único valor que realmente agregas es cuando tomas una decisión que a la mayoría no le gusta.
context: Lenny asks Ben about the difficulty and pain of being a CEO and why so many people still want to start companies despite this reality. Ben explains that leaders must develop the psychological strength to make extremely difficult decisions where all options appear terrible. He emphasizes that true leadership value comes from making unpopular but necessary decisions that others wouldn't make on their own.
vocabulary_highlights: click in the abyss, didn't add any value

speaker: Ben Horowitz
speaker_expertise: Venture Capital, Product Management, Company Building
text: What I was trying to get out in Good Product Manager, Bad Product Manager, was the job is fundamentally a leadership job. And it's a tricky leadership job because nobody is actually reporting to you.
text_ko: 제가 'Good Product Manager, Bad Product Manager'에서 말하려던 건, 프로덕트 매니저(Product Manager)라는 직무가 근본적으로 리더십 역할(leadership job)이라는 거예요. 그리고 이건 까다로운 리더십 역할인데, 그 이유는 실제로 아무도 당신에게 직접 보고하지 않기 때문이에요.
text_zh: 我在《好的产品经理，坏的产品经理》里想说的是，这个岗位本质上就是个领导职位。而且这个领导职位特别有挑战性，因为实际上没有人直接向你汇报。
text_es: Lo que trataba de transmitir en "Good Product Manager, Bad Product Manager" es que el trabajo es fundamentalmente un puesto de liderazgo. Y es un liderazgo complicado porque en realidad nadie te reporta directamente.
context: Lenny mentions Ben's famous piece 'Good Product Manager, Bad Product Manager' and asks about its relevance today. Ben explains that when he wrote this internal document at Netscape, he was trying to help product managers understand that their role is primarily about leadership, not just completing tasks like writing specs or conducting interviews. The challenge is that PMs must lead without having direct authority over the people they need to influence.
vocabulary_highlights: tricky leadership job, reporting to you

speaker: Ben Horowitz
speaker_expertise: Venture Capital, Product Management, Company Building
text: Probably one of my bigger ones on that was we went public with $2 million in trailing 12 months revenue at 18 months old. That's obviously a bad idea. But the truth of it was the alternative was going bankrupt, and that's a worse idea.
text_ko: 그와 관련해 제가 저지른 큰 실수 중 하나는 설립한 지 18개월밖에 안 됐을 때 최근 12개월 매출(trailing 12 months revenue)이 200만 달러인 상태로 상장했다는 거예요. 분명히 그건 안 좋은 결정이었어요. 그런데 사실 다른 선택지는 파산하는 것뿐이었고, 그건 더 나쁜 선택이었어요.
text_zh: 我犯的比较大的错误之一就是，公司才18个月大的时候我们就上市了，当时过去12个月的收入才200万美元。这明显是个糟糕的决定。但实话说，当时要么这样，要么破产，破产显然更糟糕。
text_es: Probablemente uno de mis errores más grandes fue que salimos a bolsa con solo 2 millones de dólares en ingresos de los últimos 12 meses cuando la empresa tenía apenas 18 meses. Obviamente es una pésima idea. Pero la realidad era que la alternativa era quebrar, y eso es aún peor.
context: Ben is discussing the importance of running towards fear and making difficult decisions as a leader, even when both available options seem terrible. He shares a personal example from his CEO experience where he had to choose between two bad alternatives. Ben explains that hesitation is the worst thing a leader can do, and sometimes you must choose the less terrible option even when it will result in harsh criticism.
vocabulary_highlights: trailing 12 months revenue, going bankrupt

speaker: Ben Horowitz
speaker_expertise: Venture Capital, Product Management, Company Building
text: The only reason to start a company is because you have an irrational desire to do so, because it's not worth the money. So I think if you're doing it for the money, that's a very bad reason and it will be extremely difficult to get you an outcome.
text_ko: 창업을 하는 유일한 이유는 그걸 하고 싶다는 비합리적인 열망이 있어서예요. 돈 때문에 할 일은 아니거든요. 돈을 목적으로 한다면 그건 아주 나쁜 이유이고 원하는 성과를 얻기 굉장히 어려울 거예요.
text_zh: 创业的唯一理由就是你有一种说不上来的冲动想去做这件事，因为单纯为了赚钱的话根本不值得。所以我觉得如果你是冲着钱去的，那动机就很有问题，最后也很难有什么好结果。
text_es: La única razón para montar una empresa es porque tienes unas ganas irracionales de hacerlo, porque por la plata no vale la pena. Así que creo que si lo haces por el dinero, es una razón muy mala y va a ser súper difícil que logres buenos resultados.
context: Lenny asks Ben who should not start companies and what advice he gives to people considering entrepreneurship who may not understand what they're getting into. Ben shares wisdom from John Reed, former CEO of Citigroup, about the true motivation needed for starting a company. He emphasizes that founders need a deeper purpose beyond financial gain to survive the inevitable challenges of building a company.
vocabulary_highlights: irrational desire, get you an outcome

speaker: Ben Horowitz
speaker_expertise: Venture Capital, Product Management, Company Building
text: You don't make people great. You find people that make you great, that make the company great, that you learned from, not the other way around. What's leverage is if you're telling me what you should do and how you can push the company forward, that's leverage, then I'm getting more than I'd have if you weren't there.
text_ko: 사람을 훌륭하게 만드는 건 당신이 아니에요. 대신 당신이 할 일은 당신을 훌륭하게 만드는 사람들, 회사를 훌륭하게 만드는 사람들, 그리고 당신이 배울 사람들을 찾아내는 거예요. 그 반대가 아니에요. 진짜 레버리지(leverage)는 당신이 뭘 해야 하는지, 어떻게 회사를 앞으로 이끌어갈 수 있는지 제게 말해주는 사람이에요. 그게 레버리지예요. 그러면 당신이 없었더라면 못 얻었을 더 많은 가치를 제가 얻게 되는 거죠.
text_zh: 你不是去培养牛人，而是要找到那些能让你变牛、让公司变牛的人，你要从他们身上学东西，而不是反过来。真正的杠杆效应(leverage)是什么？就是你能告诉我该怎么做，怎么推动公司往前走，这才叫杠杆效应，这样我得到的价值比没有你的时候要大得多。
text_es: No haces grande a la gente. Encuentras a personas que te hacen grande a ti, que hacen grande a la empresa, personas de las que tú aprendes, no al revés. Lo que realmente tiene valor es cuando tú me dices qué deberíamos hacer y cómo puedes impulsar la empresa hacia adelante, eso sí es apalancamiento (leverage), ahí es cuando obtengo más de lo que tendría si tú no estuvieras.
context: Lenny shares a story from Ali Ghodsi (CEO of Databricks) about advice Ben gave him when he became CEO regarding low performers on his team. Ben explains the concept of 'managerial leverage' - the difference between spending time developing people versus finding people who can drive the company forward independently. He emphasizes that as a CEO, you should focus on hiring people who can teach you and push the company forward, rather than trying to coach people in areas where you lack expertise.
vocabulary_highlights: managerial leverage, push the company forward

speaker: Ben Horowitz
speaker_expertise: Venture Capital, Product Management, Company Building
text: There's a very consistent thing that happens, which is when somebody doesn't make it and it kind of starts with confidence is the way I would put it. And then if you lose confidence, what happens is you hesitate on the next decision.
text_ko: 항상 비슷한 일이 생겨요. 누군가 잘 안 되기 시작하면, 제 표현대로라면 그건 자신감에서부터 시작돼요. 자신감을 잃으면 다음 결정을 내릴 때 주저하게 돼요.
text_zh: 有个很常见的现象，就是当有人做不成事的时候，我觉得根源往往是自信心出了问题。一旦失去自信，接下来做决定的时候就会犹豫不决。
text_es: Hay algo que pasa de manera muy consistente, y es cuando alguien no la logra, y yo diría que todo empieza con el tema de la confianza. Y luego, si pierdes la confianza, lo que pasa es que dudas en la siguiente decisión.
context: Lenny asks Ben when it actually makes sense to replace a founder as CEO, flipping the question about A16Z's philosophy of helping founders stay in their roles. Ben explains the pattern he's observed when founders fail as CEOs. He describes how the natural mistakes that come with learning to run a company can lead to a loss of confidence, which then creates hesitation in decision-making, ultimately leading to organizational dysfunction.
vocabulary_highlights: doesn't make it, hesitate on the next decision

speaker: Ben Horowitz
speaker_expertise: Venture Capital, Product Management, Company Building
text: I think the thing that's right about what Sam is saying is the landscape is early, really early. The technology is very immature. As amazingly as it works, there's a long way to go to improve it. So it's very possible when you have that much technological change, that the positions that these companies have achieved with their high revenue isn't sustainable.
text_ko: 샘이 말한 것 중 맞는 건 지금 시장 환경(landscape)이 초기 단계라는 거예요. 정말 초반이에요. 기술(technology)은 아직 많이 미성숙해요. 놀랍게도 잘 작동하긴 하지만 개선할 부분이 훨씬 많아요. 그래서 기술 변화가 그만큼 크면 이 회사들이 높은 매출로 차지한 위치가 오래 유지되기 힘들 수 있어요.
text_zh: 我觉得Sam说得对的地方在于，这个赛道还很早期，真的是非常早期。技术还很不成熟。虽然现在效果已经很惊人了，但要改进的地方还有很多很多。所以当技术变化这么大的时候，这些公司现在凭借高营收占据的位置很可能是站不住脚的。
text_es: Creo que Sam tiene razón en algo: estamos en las primeras etapas, muy temprano todavía. La tecnología está muy verde aún. Por más increíble que funcione, le falta un mundo por mejorar. Entonces es muy probable que con tantos cambios tecnológicos, las posiciones que han logrado estas empresas con sus altos ingresos no sean sostenibles a largo plazo.
context: Lenny asks Ben about the potential AI bubble, referencing Sam Altman's recent comments that 'we're in a big bubble.' Ben analyzes Sam's statement, first noting that it's strategically smart for Sam to say this as a CEO. He then gives his perspective on whether AI is actually in a bubble, explaining that while he doesn't think it's a financial bubble like the dot-com era, there could be competitive disruption due to the immaturity of the technology.
vocabulary_highlights: landscape is early, isn't sustainable

speaker: Ben Williams
text: We have a side car product called Snyk Advisor. Snyk Advisor, it's basically a service that developers use to search and find open source packages when they're considering integrating some within their software applications. The unique thing about it is it indexes all of the package managers. It learns about those packages. It augments the data about them with a bunch of metadata, including of course Snyk security scans, but we also find out how actively maintained the software is on the source repo on GitHub or wherever.
text_ko: Snyk Advisor라는 사이드카(sidecar) 제품이 있어요. Snyk Advisor는 기본적으로 개발자들이 소프트웨어에 통합하려고 할 때 오픈 소스 패키지(open source packages)를 검색하고 찾아보는 데 쓰는 서비스예요. 이 제품의 특징은 모든 패키지 매니저(package managers)를 인덱싱한다는 점이에요. 패키지에 대해 학습하고 여러 메타데이터(metadata)를 덧붙여 정보를 보강해요. 물론 Snyk의 보안 스캔(Snyk security scans) 결과도 포함되고, GitHub 같은 소스 저장소(source repo)에서 얼마나 활발히 유지관리되는지도 확인해요.
text_zh: 我们有个配套产品叫Snyk Advisor。Snyk Advisor说白了就是给开发者用的，他们要往自己的软件应用里集成一些开源包的时候，可以用这个服务来搜索和找包。它最牛的地方就是把所有的包管理器都索引了，了解这些包的情况，然后用一大堆元数据来丰富这些包的信息，当然包括我们Snyk的安全扫描，另外我们还会去看这个软件在GitHub或者其他源码库里维护得活跃不活跃。
text_es: Tenemos un producto complementario que se llama Snyk Advisor. Snyk Advisor es básicamente un servicio que usan los desarrolladores para buscar y encontrar paquetes de código abierto (open source) cuando están considerando integrar algunos en sus aplicaciones de software. Lo que lo hace único es que indexa todos los gestores de paquetes (package managers). Aprende sobre esos paquetes. Enriquece la información sobre ellos con un montón de metadatos, incluyendo por supuesto los escaneos de seguridad de Snyk, pero también averiguamos qué tan activamente se mantiene el software en el repositorio fuente (source repo) en GitHub o donde sea.
context: Lenny asks Ben about the growth tactics and content loops that have worked well for Snyk beyond their GitHub pull request strategy. Ben explains one of their successful programmatic SEO strategies through a product called Snyk Advisor. This tool helps developers search and evaluate open source packages by providing comprehensive metadata including security information and maintenance activity. The strategy works as a growth loop because developers searching for packages on Google find Snyk's indexed pages in search results, learn about package security, and are then directed to sign up for Snyk's main security platform.
vocabulary_highlights: side car product, augments the data, bunch of metadata
topics: Growth & Marketing, Product Management, Strategy & Planning

speaker: Ben Williams
text: At the time, the only buyers were security teams and dev first Security for the most part wasn't something that CISOs and ApSec leaders were driving. But if you look at Snyk through that lens of, as I mentioned, being a change agent, being a key piece of the transformational journey of our customers' DevSecOps journeys, you realize how important it was for us to start to build relationships with those security leaders.
text_ko: 그 당시에는 보안 팀이 유일한 구매자였고, 대부분의 경우 보안(Security)은 CISOs나 ApSec 리더들이 주도하는 게 아니었어요. 하지만 Snyk을 고객들의 DevSecOps 여정에서 변화의 주체(change agent)로서 바라보면, 그 보안 리더들과 관계를 맺는 게 얼마나 중요한지 깨닫게 돼요.
text_zh: 当时，买我们产品的基本上只有安全团队和开发团队，安全这块事儿大多数情况下都不是CISO和应用安全(ApSec)负责人在推动的。但是如果你从我刚才说的那个角度来看Snyk——把它当作一个变革推动者，当作客户DevSecOps转型路上的关键一环——你就会意识到我们开始跟这些安全负责人建立关系有多重要了。
text_es: En ese momento, los únicos que compraban eran los equipos de seguridad y los desarrolladores. La seguridad en primer lugar no era algo que estuvieran impulsando los CISOs y los líderes de seguridad de aplicaciones (ApSec). Pero si ves a Snyk desde esa perspectiva de, como mencioné, ser un agente de cambio, ser una pieza clave en el proceso de transformación del DevSecOps de nuestros clientes, te das cuenta de lo importante que era para nosotros empezar a construir relaciones con esos líderes de seguridad.
context: Lenny asks about Snyk's early monetization challenges when their self-serve model struggled to gain traction with larger companies. Ben explains that in the early days, Snyk was ahead of the curve with their developer-first security approach. The problem was that security decisions were still controlled by traditional security teams (CISOs and Application Security leaders) who weren't yet driving developer-first initiatives. Ben describes how Snyk needed to position itself as a change agent helping companies transform their DevSecOps practices, which required building relationships with security decision-makers rather than just focusing on developer adoption.
vocabulary_highlights: change agent, transformational journey, DevSecOps journeys
topics: Strategy & Planning, Leadership & Management, Decision Making

speaker: Ben Williams
text: The ideal state is that every growth team member has common vocabulary. They're comfortable with the growth process. They can work well with data and experimentation platform. They understand the data. They have the right skills and mindset. Education I think plays a big part here. So we're big fans of Reforge, but we've also developed a bunch of internal programs to align and uplevel the teams.
text_ko: 이상적인 상태는 모든 성장 팀 멤버가 공통의 용어를 가지고 있는 거예요. 그들은 성장 프로세스에 익숙하고, 데이터와 실험 플랫폼을 잘 활용할 수 있어야 해요. 데이터를 이해하고, 필요한 기술과 마인드셋을 갖추는 것도 중요하고요. 교육이 여기서 큰 역할을 한다고 생각해요. 그래서 저희는 Reforge를 정말 좋아하지만, 팀을 정렬하고 수준을 높이기 위해 내부 프로그램도 많이 개발했어요.
text_zh: 理想状态就是增长团队(growth team)的每个人都说得上话，对增长流程都很熟悉，能熟练使用数据和实验平台(experimentation platform)，看得懂数据，技能和思维方式都到位。我觉得培训在这方面特别重要。我们很推崇Reforge，但也自己搞了不少内部项目来让团队步调一致、水平提升。
text_es: El estado ideal es que todos los miembros del equipo de crecimiento manejen el mismo vocabulario. Que se sientan cómodos con el proceso de growth. Que sepan trabajar bien con datos y plataformas de experimentación. Que entiendan realmente los datos. Que tengan las habilidades y la mentalidad correcta. Creo que la capacitación juega un papel clave aquí. Somos muy fans de Reforge, pero también hemos desarrollado un montón de programas internos para alinear y elevar el nivel de los equipos.
context: Lenny asks Ben for advice on building effective growth teams, particularly in B2B product-led sales environments. Ben is explaining the first pillar of building successful growth teams: people and process. He emphasizes that team members need to be properly equipped with both skills and knowledge to do their best work. Ben explains that everyone on the growth team should share a common vocabulary around growth concepts, be comfortable with data and experimentation, and have the right mindset for growth work, which often involves rapid iteration and being comfortable with imperfection.
vocabulary_highlights: common vocabulary, uplevel the teams, align and uplevel
topics: Leadership & Management, Coaching & Development, Strategy & Planning

speaker: Ben Williams
text: You're never going to have a shortage of ideas in a high performing growth team. So, knowing where to focus amidst that kind of sea of ideas is a really important role of the strategy. Being able to identify the various micro and macro loops, how they're all connected, being able to document them in a qualitative model to communicate a shared understanding of how you grow, it's really powerful.
text_ko: 성과 좋은 그로스 팀(growth team)에선 아이디어가 부족할 일이 전혀 없어요. 그래서 그 많은 아이디어 속에서 어디에 집중할지 아는 게 전략의 핵심 역할이에요. 다양한 마이크로 루프와 매크로 루프(micro and macro loops)를 찾아내고 이들이 어떻게 연결되는지 파악해서 정성적 모델(qualitative model)로 문서화해 우리가 어떻게 성장하는지에 대한 공통된 이해를 공유할 수 있으면 정말 강력해요.
text_zh: 在一个高效增长团队里，点子肯定不会缺，关键是在这么多想法里知道该重点搞哪个，这就是战略的核心作用了。你得能识别出各种微观和宏观的循环(micro and macro loops)，搞清楚它们之间怎么相互影响，然后用一个定性模型把这些都梳理出来，让团队对增长逻辑有个共同认知，这招真的很管用。
text_es: En un equipo de alto rendimiento enfocado en crecimiento nunca te van a faltar ideas. Entonces, saber dónde enfocar tus esfuerzos en medio de ese mar de ideas es donde la estrategia juega un papel súper importante. Poder identificar los diferentes bucles micro y macro (micro and macro loops), cómo están todos conectados, poder documentarlos en un modelo cualitativo para comunicar una comprensión compartida de cómo creces, eso es realmente poderoso.
context: Ben is explaining the importance of having a clear growth strategy to guide team execution. He's discussing how successful growth teams generate many ideas, but the real challenge is knowing where to focus efforts. Ben advocates for using a loop-based model to document and understand growth mechanisms. This involves identifying both small-scale (micro) and large-scale (macro) growth loops, understanding how they connect, and creating a shared framework that helps teams prioritize where to invest their time and resources among numerous potential opportunities.
vocabulary_highlights: sea of ideas, micro and macro loops, qualitative model
topics: Strategy & Planning, Growth & Marketing, Decision Making

speaker: Ben Williams
text: We track a metric that we call product-driven revenue, which basically accounts for all revenue in customers where we saw meaningful value-based activity in the product before there was any sales contact. And that really tells actually a super interesting story about the PLG efficiency of your company across all revenue channels, self-serve and sales-led.
text_ko: 저희는 '제품 주도 수익(product-driven revenue)'이라는 지표를 추적해요. 이 지표는 영업팀과 접촉하기 전에 제품에서 의미 있는 가치 기반 활동(value-based activity)이 관찰된 고객들로부터 발생한 모든 수익을 포함해요. 그리고 이건 셀프 서비스(self-serve)든 영업 주도(sales-led)든 모든 수익 채널 전반에서 회사의 제품 주도 성장(PLG) 효율성에 대해 굉장히 흥미로운 시사점을 제공해요.
text_zh: 我们追踪一个指标，叫做产品驱动收入(product-driven revenue)，基本上就是统计那些在销售接触之前，我们就看到客户在产品里有明显价值行为的所有收入。这个指标其实能很好地反映你们公司在各个收入渠道上的PLG效率怎么样，不管是自助服务还是销售主导的都包括。
text_es: Hacemos seguimiento a una métrica que llamamos ingresos impulsados por producto (product-driven revenue), que básicamente incluye todos los ingresos de clientes donde vimos actividad significativa basada en valor dentro del producto antes de que hubiera cualquier contacto de ventas. Y esto realmente cuenta una historia súper interesante sobre la eficiencia PLG de tu empresa en todos los canales de ingresos, tanto autoservicio (self-serve) como dirigidos por ventas (sales-led).
context: Lenny asks about freemium strategy and how to balance what goes in free versus paid plans. Ben is explaining how Snyk thinks about their product-led growth strategy in conjunction with their sales-led motion. He describes a key metric they use called 'product-driven revenue' which measures revenue from customers who engaged meaningfully with the product before any sales interaction occurred. This metric helps them understand how effectively their product-led approach contributes to overall business growth, even when sales teams are involved in closing deals.
vocabulary_highlights: product-driven revenue, meaningful value-based activity, PLG efficiency
topics: Growth & Marketing, Strategy & Planning, Product Management

speaker: Ben Williams
text: Flow is just this incredibly important concept for developers and you want to strive to keep them in that flow for as long as possible. The GitHub kind of pool requests are a great example of that. Someone can sign up for Snyk and they could theoretically be the only user of Snyk and connect their repos. All of a sudden we're protecting, securing those repos, a hundred, a thousand developers could be working in GitHub with that code, all benefiting from Snyk without necessarily needing to sign up.
text_ko: 플로우(flow)는 개발자에게 정말 중요한 개념이라 가능한 한 오래 그 상태를 유지하도록 노력해야 해요. GitHub의 풀 리퀘스트(pull requests)가 그런 좋은 예예요. 누군가 Snyk에 가입(sign up)해서 유일한 사용자일 수 있고 자신의 저장소(repos)를 연결할 수 있어요. 그러면 갑자기 그 저장소들이 보호되고, 그 코드로 수백·수천 명의 개발자가 GitHub에서 작업하더라도 굳이 가입하지 않아도 Snyk의 혜택을 모두 누릴 수 있어요.
text_zh: 对于开发者来说，心流状态(flow)这个概念特别重要，你得想办法让他们尽可能长时间保持在这种状态里。GitHub的那种拉取请求(pull requests)就是个很好的例子。有人注册了Snyk，理论上他可以是Snyk的唯一用户，然后连接他们的代码库。突然间我们就在保护、加固这些代码库了，可能有一百个、一千个开发者在GitHub上用这些代码工作，他们都能从Snyk中受益，而且不一定需要自己去注册。
text_es: El flujo (flow) es un concepto súper importante para los desarrolladores y quieres mantenerlos en ese flujo el mayor tiempo posible. Las pull requests de GitHub son un ejemplo perfecto de esto. Alguien puede registrarse en Snyk y teóricamente podría ser el único usuario de Snyk y conectar sus repositorios. De repente ya estamos protegiendo y asegurando esos repos, cien o mil desarrolladores podrían estar trabajando en GitHub con ese código, todos beneficiándose de Snyk sin necesariamente tener que registrarse.
context: Lenny asks Ben about lessons for companies targeting developers and how to win their hearts and minds. Ben is explaining that the key to developer adoption is meeting developers where they already work rather than pulling them out of their existing workflows. He uses the concept of 'flow state' - when developers are deeply focused and productive - and explains how Snyk's GitHub integration allows developers to benefit from security improvements without disrupting their normal coding workflow. This approach allows one Snyk user to generate value for entire development teams without requiring everyone to sign up.
vocabulary_highlights: flow state, keep them in that flow, theoretically be the only user
topics: Product Management, Growth & Marketing, Strategy & Planning

speaker: Benjamin Lauzier
text: I think when you're running a marketplace, you tend to sit in your ivory tower a little bit, looking at stats and thinking like, 'If only we could get people to do X, it'd be better for everyone.' I certainly did that in my career. I think that's missing the point that we're humans, and I think sometimes we act in ways that are non-deterministic or counterintuitive.
text_ko: 마켓플레이스(marketplace)를 운영하다 보면 통계만 들여다보며 '사람들이 X만 하게 만들 수 있다면 모두에게 더 좋을 텐데'라고 탑 속에 틀어박힌 듯 생각하게 돼요. 저도 제 커리어 내내 그랬어요. 그런데 그건 핵심을 놓치는 거예요. 우리는 사람이고, 때로는 행동이 비결정적(non-deterministic)이거나 직관에 반하는(counterintuitive) 방식으로 움직이기도 하거든요.
text_zh: 我觉得做平台的时候，你很容易就坐在象牙塔里，天天盯着数据看，然后想"要是能让用户这样做就好了，对大家都有好处。" 我以前也这样。但我觉得这样想就没抓住重点——我们都是人啊，有时候做事就是不按套路出牌，或者跟你预想的完全相反。
text_es: Creo que cuando manejas una plataforma o marketplace, tiendes a quedarte un poco en tu burbuja, viendo estadísticas y pensando "si tan solo pudiéramos lograr que la gente haga X, sería mejor para todos." Yo mismo lo hice durante mi carrera. Pero creo que ahí se pierde de vista que somos humanos, y a veces actuamos de maneras que no son deterministas o que van contra la lógica.
context: Lenny asks about Benjamin's thoughts on managed marketplaces and when companies should consider becoming more managed. Benjamin explains that marketplace operators often think they can optimize user behavior by adding more controls, but this overlooks human psychology. He's sharing his perspective on why trying to over-control marketplace participants often backfires because people don't always act rationally or predictably.
vocabulary_highlights: sit in your ivory tower, non-deterministic, counterintuitive

speaker: Benjamin Lauzier
text: My take is I'm a huge believer in market forces and empowerment, so provide guardrails for what a good experience is in your marketplace, set a clear bar for quality, and provide the right coaching and tools for supply to be successful, and then take a step back and see where the gaps are and invest more in hands-on tactics just to close those gaps more specifically.
text_ko: 제 생각엔 시장의 힘(market forces)과 권한 부여(empowerment)를 굉장히 신뢰해요. 그래서 마켓플레이스(marketplace)에서 좋은 경험이 무엇인지에 대한 가이드라인(guardrails)을 제시하고, 품질 기준을 분명히 정한 다음 공급자(supply)가 성공할 수 있도록 적절한 코칭(coaching)과 도구(tools)를 제공해줘야 해요. 그런 다음 한 발 물러서서 어디에 격차가 있는지 보고, 그 격차를 메우기 위해 좀 더 실무적인 전술에 추가로 투자하면 된다고 봐요.
text_zh: 我的想法是这样的，我特别相信市场力量和赋能这一套，所以你要给市场体验设个框框，把质量标准定得清清楚楚，然后给供应方提供合适的指导和工具让他们能做成事，接下来你就往后退一步，看看哪里还有缺口，再针对性地投入一些实操手段把这些缺口给补上。
text_es: Mi punto de vista es que creo muchísimo en las fuerzas del mercado y el empoderamiento, entonces tienes que poner barandillas para definir qué es una buena experiencia en tu marketplace, establecer un listón claro de calidad, y dar el coaching y las herramientas correctas para que la oferta tenga éxito, y después dar un paso atrás para ver dónde están los huecos e invertir más en tácticas más directas para cerrar esos gaps específicos.
context: Benjamin is explaining his philosophy on how to manage marketplace quality without over-controlling participants. Rather than micromanaging every aspect of the marketplace experience, he advocates for setting quality standards and providing support tools, then only intervening with direct management where specific problems emerge. This approach balances maintaining quality while preserving the marketplace model's efficiency.
vocabulary_highlights: market forces, set a clear bar, take a step back, hands-on tactics

speaker: Benjamin Lauzier
text: If you don't have product market fit, and if you don't have a good enough growth strategy for at least one side of your marketplace, just forget about all this marketplace stuff. Focus on this core exchange of value, go deep with one side of the marketplace and see if you can rely on some crutch, some hack for the other side for time being.
text_ko: 제품·시장 적합성(product-market fit)이 없고, 마켓플레이스(marketplace)에서 최소한 한 쪽에 대해 충분히 좋은 성장 전략(growth strategy)도 없다면 그런 마켓플레이스 얘기는 접어두세요. 가치의 핵심 교환(core exchange of value)에 집중해서 마켓플레이스의 한 쪽을 깊게 파고들고, 다른 쪽은 당분간 지렛대나 임시방편(hack)에 의존할 수 있는지 확인해 보세요.
text_zh: 如果你的产品还没有找到市场契合点(product market fit)，如果你连marketplace一边的增长策略都搞不定，那就别折腾什么双边市场了。先把核心的价值交换做扎实，深耕一边的用户，另一边先想办法用些取巧的办法撑着，能凑合就行。
text_es: Si no tienes product market fit, y si no tienes una estrategia de crecimiento lo suficientemente buena para al menos un lado de tu marketplace, olvídate de todo este rollo del marketplace. Enfócate en este intercambio de valor central, profundiza con un lado del marketplace y ve si puedes apoyarte en algún truco, algún hack para el otro lado mientras tanto.
context: Lenny asks about the biggest struggles in building successful marketplace businesses. Benjamin explains that pre-product market fit, founders often get distracted by complex marketplace dynamics when they should focus on basics. His advice is to concentrate on creating value for one side of the marketplace first, using temporary solutions or shortcuts for the other side until you establish that core value proposition works.
vocabulary_highlights: core exchange of value, go deep with, rely on some crutch, for time being
topics: Starting a Company, Product Management, Strategy & Planning

speaker: Benjamin Lauzier
text: Pick the hardest side is my advice. And then, how some companies do this, again, I think there's a lot of different ways to do this, but a common advice is find a way to jumpstart one side. Find a way to hack one side, play one player mode is what it's also called sometimes, but try to find a way to tap into existing channels that have one side of your marketplace already latent.
text_ko: 제 조언은 가장 어려운 쪽을 택하라는 거예요. 이걸 실행하는 방법은 여러 가지가 있는데, 흔한 조언은 한쪽을 먼저 활성화시킬 방법을 찾으라는 거예요 — 한쪽을 빠르게 시작(jumpstart)하거나 한쪽을 해킹(hack)해서 확보하는 식으로요. 때로는 '플레이 원 플레이어 모드(play one player mode)'라고도 부르는데, 핵심은 이미 한 쪽 사용자층이 잠재해 있는 기존 채널을 어떻게든 끌어와서 당신의 마켓플레이스(marketplace) 한 쪽을 먼저 채우는 거예요.
text_zh: 我建议你选择比较难搞定的那一边。然后呢，关于怎么去做这件事，我觉得不同公司有很多不同的玩法，但有个比较通用的建议就是想办法先把一边给带起来。想办法去hack一边，有时候也叫单人模式(play one player mode)，就是尽量去挖掘那些已经有你平台一方用户的现成渠道。
text_es: Mi consejo es que te enfoques en el lado más difícil. Y luego, sobre cómo algunas empresas hacen esto, creo que hay muchas formas distintas de abordarlo, pero un consejo común es encontrar una manera de darle impulso a un lado. Buscar la forma de hackear un lado, a veces le dicen "modo un jugador" (player one mode), pero trata de encontrar una manera de aprovechar canales que ya existen y que tienen un lado de tu marketplace de forma latente.
context: Lenny asks how to determine which side of a marketplace to focus on initially and for examples of how companies like Thumbtack approached this. Benjamin explains that founders should focus on the more challenging side to acquire, then find creative ways to bootstrap the other side. He introduces the concept of 'one player mode' where you temporarily solve one side through existing platforms or manual processes.
vocabulary_highlights: jumpstart one side, hack one side, one player mode, tap into existing channels, already latent

speaker: Benjamin Lauzier
text: To me, liquidity is how marketplaces win. It's this measure of your ability to match buyers and sellers efficiently, it's how quickly and efficiently people can find what they're looking for on your platform. So, you can picture a Venn diagram. One circle is this is what supply wants to sell, and another circle is this is what demand wants to buy, and your liquidity is the overlap between those two circles.
text_ko: 제게 유동성(liquidity)은 마켓플레이스(marketplaces)가 이기는 방식이에요. 구매자와 판매자를 얼마나 빠르고 효율적으로 매칭할 수 있는지를 보여주는 척도고, 사람들이 플랫폼에서 원하는 걸 얼마나 빨리 그리고 수월하게 찾을 수 있는가를 뜻하기도 해요. 벤다이어그램(Venn diagram)을 떠올려 보세요. 한 쪽 원은 공급(supply)이 팔고 싶어하는 것, 다른 쪽 원은 수요(demand)가 사고 싶어하는 것이고, 유동성은 그 두 원이 겹치는 부분이에요.
text_zh: 在我看来，流动性(liquidity)就是平台制胜的关键。它衡量的是你能多有效地撮合买卖双方，也就是用户在你平台上能多快多准地找到他们想要的东西。你可以想象一个韦恩图，一个圆圈代表供应方想卖的，另一个圆圈代表需求方想买的，而你的流动性就是这两个圆圈重叠的部分。
text_es: Para mí, la liquidez es lo que hace que los mercados digitales triunfen. Es como mides tu capacidad para conectar compradores y vendedores de manera eficiente, es qué tan rápido y fácil la gente puede encontrar lo que busca en tu plataforma. Imagínate un diagrama de Venn. Un círculo es "esto es lo que la oferta (supply) quiere vender", y el otro círculo es "esto es lo que la demanda (demand) quiere comprar", y tu liquidez es donde se traslapan esos dos círculos.
context: Benjamin is explaining the concept of marketplace liquidity, which he identifies as a key challenge for scaled marketplace companies that have achieved product-market fit. Liquidity measures how well a marketplace can successfully match supply and demand - essentially how often people with intent to buy or sell actually complete transactions. He's using a Venn diagram analogy to visualize this critical marketplace metric.
vocabulary_highlights: liquidity is how marketplaces win, overlap between those two circles

speaker: Benjamin Lauzier
text: The metric that I think is slightly more actionable is a little harder to define, but so much more helpful in my opinion. It's what I call a market health metric, and this is basically think of your proxy that is the best predictor of your liquidity.
text_ko: 제가 좀 더 실행 가능하다고 생각하는 지표는 정의하기가 좀 더 어렵지만 제 생각엔 훨씬 더 유용해요. 저는 이를 '시장 건강 지표(market health metric)'라고 부르는데, 기본적으로 유동성(liquidity)을 가장 잘 예측해 주는 대리 지표(proxy)를 떠올리시면 돼요.
text_zh: 我觉得有个指标更有实操性，虽然定义起来有点难，但在我看来要有用得多。我把它叫做市场健康度指标(market health metric)，基本上就是找一个最能预测你流动性的代理指标(proxy)。
text_es: La métrica que me parece un poco más práctica es algo más difícil de definir, pero en mi opinión es muchísimo más útil. Es lo que yo llamo una métrica de salud del mercado, y básicamente es pensar en tu indicador indirecto que sea el mejor predictor de tu liquidez.
context: Benjamin is discussing how to measure marketplace performance beyond just looking at conversion rates (liquidity). He explains that while liquidity - like how many app opens turn into rides - is important, teams need a more actionable metric. A market health metric serves as a leading indicator that predicts liquidity, such as driver proximity (ETAs) for rideshare apps, which directly correlates with whether users will complete bookings.
vocabulary_highlights: slightly more actionable, market health metric, proxy that is the best predictor

speaker: Benjamin Lauzier
text: I think the signs that come to mind are one, higher fragmentation. I think you want this long tail of buyers and sellers without a handful of big players controlling the market, because this is where you can provide value by doing this job of aggregation.
text_ko: 제가 떠올리는 징후 중 하나는 시장의 파편화(fragmentation)가 더 심해진다는 점이에요. 소수의 대형 플레이어가 시장을 장악하지 않고 구매자와 판매자가 롱테일(long tail)로 분포한 상태를 원하는데, 그런 곳에서 집계(aggregation) 역할을 하면서 가치를 제공할 수 있기 때문이에요.
text_zh: 我觉得有几个明显的迹象，第一个就是市场更加碎片化。你肯定希望有很多小买家小卖家，而不是让几个大玩家控制整个市场，因为只有这样你才能通过做聚合这件事来创造价值。
text_es: Creo que las señales que se me ocurren son, primero, mayor fragmentación. Pienso que necesitas esa cola larga (long tail) de compradores y vendedores sin que un puñado de jugadores grandes controlen el mercado, porque ahí es donde puedes aportar valor haciendo este trabajo de agregación.
context: Lenny asks what signals indicate that a marketplace business model is right for a particular idea or vertical. Benjamin explains the first key indicator: market fragmentation. He's describing how marketplaces thrive when there are many small participants on both sides rather than a few dominant players, because the marketplace's value proposition is aggregating and connecting these fragmented participants who otherwise couldn't easily find each other.
vocabulary_highlights: higher fragmentation, long tail of buyers and sellers, handful of big players, job of aggregation

speaker: Benjamin Mann
text: We've been much less affected because people here, they get these offers and then they say, well, of course I'm not going to leave because my best case scenario at Meta is that we make money and my best case scenario at Anthropic is we affect the future of humanity.
text_ko: 우리는 훨씬 덜 영향을 받았어요. 여기 사람들은 이런 제안을 받으면 보통 “당연히 떠나지 않아요. Meta에서의 최상의 시나리오(best case scenario)는 우리가 돈을 버는 거고, Anthropic에서의 최상의 시나리오는 인류의 미래에 영향을 미치는 거예요.”라고 말해요.
text_zh: 我们受到的影响要小得多，因为我们这里的人收到那些offer之后会说，我当然不会走啊，在Meta最好的情况就是赚到钱，但在Anthropic最好的情况是我们能影响人类的未来。
text_es: Hemos sido mucho menos afectados porque la gente aquí, cuando les llegan estas ofertas, pues dicen, claro, obviamente no me voy a ir porque en el mejor de los casos en Meta ganamos dinero, pero en el mejor de los casos en Anthropic impactamos el futuro de la humanidad.
context: Lenny asks Benjamin about Meta's aggressive recruiting strategy where Zuck is offering $100 million signing bonuses to poach top AI researchers from other labs. Benjamin explains how Anthropic has been less affected by these massive compensation offers compared to other AI companies. He describes how Anthropic employees are mission-oriented and decline these offers because they prioritize making an impact on humanity's future over purely financial gains.
vocabulary_highlights: much less affected, best case scenario, affect the future of humanity

speaker: Benjamin Mann
text: If you just think about the amount of impact that individuals can have on a company's trajectory, in our case, we are selling hotcakes and if we get a 1 or 10 or 5% efficiency bonus on our inference stack, that is worth an incredible amount of money.
text_ko: 개인이 회사의 성장 방향에 미칠 영향만 생각해 봐도, 우리의 경우에는 제품이 불티나게 팔리고 있어서 추론 스택(inference stack)의 효율이 1%든 5%든 10%든 조금만 올라가도 그게 엄청난 금전적 가치가 있어요.
text_zh: 你想想看，个人对公司发展轨迹能产生多大影响，我们现在产品卖得特别火，如果我们在推理技术栈(inference stack)上能提高1%、5%或者10%的效率，那价值就是天文数字了。
text_es: Si te pones a pensar en el impacto que pueden tener las personas en la dirección de una empresa, en nuestro caso, estamos vendiendo como pan caliente y si logramos una mejora de eficiencia del 1, 5 o 10% en nuestro inference stack, eso vale una cantidad increíble de dinero.
context: Lenny questions whether the reported $100 million signing bonuses from Meta are real. Benjamin confirms they likely are and explains the economic rationale behind such massive offers. He describes how individual AI researchers can have enormous impact on a company's success, and even small efficiency improvements to AI systems can be worth hundreds of millions in value, making these compensation packages economically justified.
vocabulary_highlights: selling hotcakes, efficiency bonus, inference stack

speaker: Benjamin Mann
text: It's kind of funny because this narrative comes out every six months or so and it's never been true, and so I kind of wish people would have a little bit of a bullshit detector in their heads when they see this.
text_ko: 이 얘기가 대략 6개월마다 한 번쯤 나오는데, 재밌게도 한 번도 사실이 아니었어요. 그래서 사람들이 이런 걸 볼 때 머릿속에 약간의 헛소리 감지기(bullshit detector)를 갖고 있었으면 좋겠어요.
text_zh: 挺搞笑的，这套说辞(narrative)基本每半年就会冒出来一次，从来就没准过，所以我真希望大家看到这种东西的时候脑子里能有点辨别能力，别什么都信。
text_es: Es medio chistoso porque esta narrativa sale cada seis meses más o menos y nunca ha sido cierta, así que ojalá la gente tuviera un poco más de ojo crítico cuando vean esto.
context: Lenny mentions the common perception that AI progress has hit plateaus and that newer models aren't significantly smarter than previous versions. Benjamin pushes back on this narrative, explaining that this same claim emerges repeatedly but has never proven accurate. He suggests people need better critical thinking skills when evaluating these claims about AI progress slowing down.
vocabulary_highlights: bullshit detector

speaker: Benjamin Mann
text: I like the term transformative AI because it's less about can it do as much as people do? Can it do literally everything and more about objectively is it causing transformation in society and the economy?
text_ko: 저는 '변혁적 AI(transformative AI)'라는 표현이 좋아요. 이 말은 '사람들이 하는 만큼 할 수 있나? 말 그대로 모든 걸 할 수 있나?'를 묻는 것보다, 객관적으로 사회와 경제에 변화를 일으키고 있나를 보는 데 더 초점을 둬요.
text_zh: 我喜欢用"变革性AI(transformative AI)"这个说法，因为重点不在于它能不能做到人类能做的所有事情，能不能真的什么都会，而在于它是不是实实在在地在改变我们的社会和经济。
text_es: Me gusta el término IA transformativa porque no se trata tanto de si puede hacer todo lo que hacemos las personas, si literalmente puede hacer de todo, sino más bien de si objetivamente está generando una transformación real en la sociedad y la economía.
context: Lenny asks Benjamin about his specific way of thinking about AGI (Artificial General Intelligence). Benjamin explains that he prefers the term 'transformative AI' over AGI because it focuses on measurable societal and economic impact rather than abstract comparisons to human capabilities. He introduces the concept of the Economic Turing Test as a concrete way to measure when AI has become truly transformative.
vocabulary_highlights: transformative AI, objectively

speaker: Benjamin Mann
text: If you just think about 20 years in the future where we're way past the singularity, it's hard for me to imagine that even capitalism will look at all like it looks today.
text_ko: 앞으로 20년쯤, 특이점(singularity)을 훨씬 지난 세상을 생각해 보면 자본주의(capitalism)조차 지금과 전혀 같아 보일 것 같지 않아요.
text_zh: 你想想20年后的世界，到那时候奇点(singularity)早就过去了，我觉得连资本主义都不会是现在这个样子了。
text_es: Si te pones a pensar en cómo van a estar las cosas dentro de 20 años, cuando ya hayamos dejado atrás la singularidad tecnológica (singularity), la verdad es que se me hace muy difícil imaginar que el capitalismo se vaya a parecer en algo a lo que conocemos hoy.
context: Lenny asks about Dario's (Anthropic's CEO) prediction that AI could cause unemployment to rise to 20% and asks Benjamin about AI's impact on jobs. Benjamin responds by looking even further into the future, explaining that once we achieve superintelligence and reach the singularity, economic systems like capitalism may be fundamentally transformed beyond recognition due to the abundance that AI will create.
vocabulary_highlights: way past the singularity, at all like it looks today

speaker: Benjamin Mann
text: I'm not immune to job replacement either. At some point it's coming for all of us.
text_ko: 저도 일자리 대체에서 안전하지 않아요. 언젠가는 우리 모두에게 닥칠 일이에요.
text_zh: 我也不例外，工作被替代这事儿迟早会轮到我们每个人头上。
text_es: Yo tampoco me libro de que me reemplacen en el trabajo. En algún momento nos va a tocar a todos.
context: Lenny asks Benjamin for advice on how people can future-proof their careers against AI replacement. Benjamin shows vulnerability by admitting that even he, as someone at the center of AI development at Anthropic, is not immune to eventual job displacement by AI. This candid admission emphasizes how widespread the impact of AI on employment is likely to be across all professions and skill levels.
vocabulary_highlights: not immune to, it's coming for all of us

speaker: Benjamin Mann
text: We felt like safety wasn't the top priority there. The case for safety has gotten a lot more concrete, so superintelligence is a lot about how do we keep God in a box and not let the God out?
text_ko: 저희는 거기서 안전이 최우선이라는 느낌을 받지 못했어요. 안전에 대한 근거가 훨씬 더 구체화됐고, 그래서 초지능(superintelligence)은 결국 '신을 상자에 가두고 꺼내지 않게 하는' 방법을 찾는 문제인 경우가 많아요.
text_zh: 我们觉得安全问题在那里不是最重要的。现在安全问题变得更加具体了，所以超级智能(superintelligence)的关键就是，我们怎么把这个"上帝"关在笼子里，不让它跑出来？
text_es: Sentíamos que la seguridad no era la prioridad número uno ahí. El tema de la seguridad se ha vuelto mucho más concreto, entonces la superinteligencia se trata mucho de cómo mantenemos a Dios en una caja y no lo dejamos salir.
context: Lenny asks Benjamin why he and other founders left OpenAI to start Anthropic. Benjamin explains that they felt AI safety wasn't being prioritized highly enough at OpenAI. He uses a vivid metaphor comparing superintelligent AI to a god-like entity that needs to be contained, referencing the classic AI safety problem of how to control extremely powerful AI systems while still benefiting from their capabilities.
vocabulary_highlights: top priority, keep God in a box

speaker: Bill Carr
text: Amazon was actually, to some degree, equally focused on process innovation. In many cases, by the way, we stood on other people's shoulders, we cannot take credit for having... For most of these, there were other inspirations or we built on work that others had done, which by the way, was what I think all great companies should do. And again, that's also why we wrote the book was because we would like to allow people to stand on Amazon's shoulders to learn what we learned, and then take all or part of these things and build from there.
text_ko: 아마존은 사실 어느 정도 프로세스 혁신(process innovation)에도 똑같이 집중했어요. 참고로 많은 경우 우리는 다른 사람들의 어깨 위에 있었고, 그걸 전적으로 우리가 해낸 것처럼 공을 다 가져갈 순 없어요. 대부분은 다른 사람들에게서 영감을 받았거나, 다른 사람들이 해놓은 일을 기반으로 우리가 더한 것이었고, 저는 모든 훌륭한 회사들이 그렇게 해야 한다고 생각해요. 그리고 그게 우리가 책을 쓴 이유이기도 해요 — 사람들이 아마존의 어깨 위에 올라 우리가 배운 것을 배우고, 그걸 전부나 일부 가져가서 거기서부터 더 발전시킬 수 있게 하려는 거예요.
text_zh: 亚马逊其实在很大程度上也同样专注于流程创新。顺便说一下，很多情况下，我们都是站在别人的肩膀上，我们不能把功劳都揽到自己身上……这些东西大部分都有其他的灵感来源，或者说我们是在别人已有工作的基础上继续发展的。我觉得所有伟大的公司都应该这么做。这也是我们写这本书的原因——我们希望让大家能够站在亚马逊的肩膀上，学习我们学到的东西，然后把这些经验全部或部分拿去用，在此基础上继续往前走。
text_es: Amazon también estaba enfocado, en cierta medida, en la innovación de procesos. En muchos casos, la verdad es que nos apoyamos en el trabajo de otros, no podemos llevarnos el mérito de haber... Para la mayoría de estas cosas, tuvimos otras inspiraciones o construimos sobre el trabajo que otros ya habían hecho, y eso, por cierto, es lo que creo que todas las grandes empresas deberían hacer. Y también por eso escribimos el libro, porque nos gustaría permitir que la gente se apoye en los hombros de Amazon para aprender lo que nosotros aprendimos, y luego tomen todo o parte de estas cosas y construyan desde ahí.
context: Lenny asks Bill what made Amazon unique in creating so many innovative ways of working that have proliferated throughout the tech industry. Bill explains that while Amazon is known for product innovation like Kindle and AWS, the company was equally focused on developing new processes and ways of working. He emphasizes that Amazon built upon existing ideas and methodologies from other companies, adapting and improving them rather than creating everything from scratch.
vocabulary_highlights: stood on other people's shoulders, built on work, take all or part of these things

speaker: Bill Carr
text: So the concept of single-threaded leadership was first... When I was born from this time of complexity at Amazon, and where again, large... Once you get to a certain scale, you get to a point of where there are competing departments, competing interests, and they're competing for some centralized pool of resources. For all of you who are working for a tech company, this is this pool of engineering resources, or today, data science and AI resources.
text_ko: 단일 스레드 리더십(single-threaded leadership)이라는 개념은 아마존에서 복잡성이 커지던 시절에 처음 생겨났어요. 회사가 일정 규모를 넘어서면 부서 간 이해관계가 충돌하고, 각 부서가 중앙화된 자원 풀(centralized pool of resources)을 두고 경쟁하게 되거든요. 기술 회사에서 일하시는 분들에게 그 자원은 바로 엔지니어링 자원(engineering resources)이고, 요즘엔 데이터 사이언스와 AI 자원(data science and AI resources)이에요.
text_zh: 所以单线程领导(single-threaded leadership)这个概念最初是...当时我在亚马逊面临复杂局面时想出来的。就是说，公司一旦做大到一定规模，你就会发现各个部门开始打架，各有各的利益，大家都在抢那些集中的资源池。你们在科技公司工作的都知道，就是抢工程师资源，现在还要抢数据科学和AI资源。
text_es: Entonces el concepto de liderazgo de un solo hilo (single-threaded leadership) nació por primera vez... Cuando surgió de esta época de complejidad en Amazon, y donde otra vez, grandes... Una vez que llegas a cierta escala, llegas a un punto donde tienes departamentos que compiten entre sí, intereses que chocan, y todos están peleándose por el mismo pool centralizado de recursos. Para todos ustedes que trabajan en una empresa de tecnología, este es el pool de recursos de ingeniería, o hoy en día, recursos de ciencia de datos e IA.
context: Lenny asks Bill to explain what single-threaded leadership means and why it's effective. Bill is describing the origin of Amazon's single-threaded leader concept, explaining that it emerged when Amazon reached a scale where different departments were competing for limited centralized resources like engineering talent. This competition was creating inefficiencies and slowing down product development across the organization.
vocabulary_highlights: single-threaded leadership, competing for some centralized pool of resources

speaker: Bill Carr
text: We've moved from what we called a project orientation to a program orientation. So, a project orientation means, oh, we are going to do this project to change our search result page and algorithm, and the project is defined in this way and it's going to take six months. The resources will come and swarm on that, and then they'll move off to some other thing in some other part of the company.
text_ko: 우리가 '프로젝트 지향(project orientation)'이라고 부르던 방식에서 '프로그램 지향(program orientation)'으로 옮겼어요. 프로젝트 지향이라는 건, '이번에 검색 결과 페이지(search results page)와 알고리즘(algorithm)을 바꾸는 이 프로젝트를 하자' 하고 프로젝트를 그렇게 정의하고 기간을 6개월로 잡으면, 자원들이 그쪽에 우르르 몰려와서 집중 투입됐다가 끝나면 회사의 다른 부서에 있는 다른 일로 옮겨 가는 방식이에요.
text_zh: 我们从项目导向(project orientation)转变为计划导向(program orientation)了。项目导向就是说，比如我们要做个项目来改变搜索结果页面和算法，项目就这么定义好了，要做六个月。资源就会集中过来搞这个，搞完了就跑去公司其他地方做别的事了。
text_es: Hemos pasado de lo que llamábamos una orientación por proyectos a una orientación por programas. O sea, la orientación por proyectos significa, bueno, vamos a hacer este proyecto para cambiar nuestra página de resultados de búsqueda y el algoritmo, y el proyecto está definido de tal manera y va a tomar seis meses. Los recursos van a llegar y se van a volcar en eso, y después se van a mover a otra cosa en alguna otra área de la empresa.
context: Bill is continuing to explain the single-threaded leader model by contrasting two different organizational approaches. He's describing how Amazon shifted from temporary project-based work (where resources come together briefly for specific initiatives) to a program-based approach where dedicated teams work continuously on specific areas of the business like search functionality.
vocabulary_highlights: project orientation to a program orientation, resources will come and swarm on that

speaker: Bill Carr
text: The beauty of that though is that once we'd had those discussions, those interchanges, then the teams were free to sprint hard after their plan. They didn't have to worry about whether was, 'Am I aligned with my CEO? Am I aligned with my senior vice president?' They could know that they were. But yes, this creates then clear... If they're going to deliver it or not. It's up to that owner and that team.
text_ko: 그런데 좋은 점은 우리가 그런 논의들과 교류들을 한 번 마치고 나니까 팀들이 자기 계획을 가지고 마음껏 전력 질주(스프린트)할 수 있게 됐다는 거예요. '내가 CEO와 방향이 맞나? 시니어 부사장과 조율돼 있나?' 같은 걸 걱정할 필요가 없었고, 팀들은 이미 그렇게 맞춰져 있다는 걸 알 수 있었어요. 그리고 이렇게 되면 '이걸 정말로 해낼지'가 분명해지고, 그걸 해낼지는 결국 그 오너(owner)와 그 팀에게 달려 있어요.
text_zh: 不过这样做的好处就是，一旦我们把这些讨论都搞定了，把想法都交流透了，团队就可以放开手脚去冲刺他们的计划了。他们不用再纠结什么"我跟CEO的想法一致吗？我跟高级副总裁站在一条线上吗？"这些问题，因为他们心里有数。当然了，这样一来责任就很明确了……能不能交付出来，就看那个负责人和他的团队了。
text_es: Lo hermoso de eso es que una vez que tuvimos esas conversaciones, esos intercambios, entonces los equipos pudieron lanzarse de lleno con su plan. Ya no tenían que preocuparse por si estaban alineados con el CEO o con el vicepresidente senior, ya sabían que sí lo estaban. Pero claro, esto crea una responsabilidad muy clara... Si van a cumplir o no, eso ya depende del responsable y su equipo.
context: Lenny asks whether single-threaded leadership is about having one person's vision drive decisions. Bill clarifies that while there is one leader and team responsible, there's still an intensive review process where senior leadership scrutinizes and aligns on plans before teams execute. He's explaining how this creates clear accountability while ensuring alignment with company leadership.
vocabulary_highlights: sprint hard after their plan, those interchanges

speaker: Bill Carr
text: What it means is that have backbone and disagree, meaning when we are making any kind of a decision, important decision, if you are part of that team, part of that unit, it is your obligation to voice your point of view if you disagree with your approach that's been taken. The point of that disagreement, by the way, is to provide usually additional information or a new point of view that people have not considered.
text_ko: 이 말은 ‘소신을 가지고 반대하라(have backbone and disagree)’는 뜻이에요. 다시 말해 어떤 결정을—특히 중요한 결정일수록—내릴 때 팀이나 조직의 일원이라면 현재 취해진 접근 방식에 동의하지 않을 경우 자신의 관점을 말할 의무가 있어요. 그리고 그런 반대의 요지는 보통 사람들이 생각하지 못한 추가 정보나 새로운 시각을 제공하기 위해서예요.
text_zh: 这个意思就是说要有骨气，该反对的时候就要反对。也就是说，当我们要做什么重要决定的时候，如果你是团队的一份子，你就有责任把自己的想法说出来，特别是当你不同意现在这个做法的时候。其实disagreement的目的呢，通常是为了提供一些额外的信息，或者是大家之前没有考虑到的新角度。
text_es: Esto significa que hay que tener agallas y estar en desacuerdo cuando sea necesario. O sea, cuando estamos tomando cualquier tipo de decisión importante, si formas parte de ese equipo, de esa unidad, es tu obligación expresar tu punto de vista si no estás de acuerdo con el enfoque que se está tomando. El objetivo de ese desacuerdo, por cierto, es aportar información adicional o una perspectiva nueva que la gente no ha considerado.
context: Lenny asks Bill to explain Amazon's 'disagree and commit' principle, noting that people often misunderstand it. Bill clarifies that it starts with 'have backbone' and explains the first part - that team members have an obligation to voice disagreement when they have different perspectives. The purpose is to bring new information or viewpoints to improve decision-making, not just to be contrarian.
vocabulary_highlights: have backbone and disagree, it is your obligation to voice your point of view

speaker: Bill Carr
text: I got great advice actually from one of my managers at one point, Steve Kessel who said, 'You have to look for what that is, and then your job is to then take that kernel and try to run with it and expand it and try to see how I can take that idea, that concept, and then make it into something viable.'
text_ko: 사실 예전에 매니저였던 스티브 케슬에게서 정말 좋은 조언을 들었어요. "그게 뭔지 찾아내고, 그 핵심(kernel)을 잡아서 그걸 바탕으로 직접 밀고 나가서 확장해 보고, 그 아이디어나 개념을 어떻게 실현 가능한 형태로 만들 수 있을지 보는 게 네 일이에요."
text_zh: 其实我有个经理Steve Kessel给过我一个特别好的建议，他说："你得去找到那个点在哪里，然后你的工作就是抓住这个核心，去推进它，去扩展它，看看怎么能把这个想法、这个概念变成真正可行的东西。"
text_es: Recibí un consejo buenísimo de uno de mis jefes, Steve Kessel, que me dijo: 'Tienes que buscar cuál es esa cosa, y entonces tu trabajo es agarrar esa semillita e intentar desarrollarla y expandirla, y ver cómo puedes tomar esa idea, ese concepto, y convertirlo en algo que realmente funcione.'
context: Lenny asks Bill for advice on what to do when you still disagree after going through the disagree and commit process. Bill shares personal experience working with Jeff Bezos on ideas he didn't initially agree with. He explains how his manager Steve Kessel advised him to focus on the core kernel of the leader's thinking and try to make that concept viable, rather than just going through the motions.
vocabulary_highlights: take that kernel and try to run with it, make it into something viable

speaker: Bill Carr
text: We took it as an article of faith that if we served customers well, if we prioritized customers and delivered for them, we took it as an article of faith that then things like sales, things like revenue and active customers and things like the share price and free cash flow would follow. So therefore, when we're making a decision thinking about a problem, we're going to start with what's best for the customer and then come backward from there.
text_ko: 저희는 고객에게 잘해드리고 고객을 최우선으로 삼아 가치를 제공하면, 매출(sales)이나 수익(revenue), 활성 고객 수(active customers), 주가(share price), 잉여현금흐름(free cash flow) 같은 것들이 자연스럽게 따라온다고 믿었어요. 그래서 문제를 고민하고 결정을 내릴 때는 항상 고객에게 무엇이 가장 좋은지부터 시작해서 거기서부터 역으로 생각해요.
text_zh: 我们坚信一个道理，就是只要我们好好服务客户，把客户放在第一位，真正为他们交付价值，那么销售额啊、营收啊、活跃客户数啊，还有股价、自由现金流(free cash flow)这些东西自然就会跟上来。所以我们在做决策、思考问题的时候，都是先考虑什么对客户最好，然后再往回推。
text_es: Nosotros teníamos la convicción absoluta de que si atendíamos bien a los clientes, si los poníamos como prioridad y les cumplíamos, teníamos la fe ciega de que entonces todo lo demás iba a venir solo: las ventas, los ingresos, los clientes activos, el precio de las acciones y el flujo de caja libre (free cash flow). Por eso, cuando estamos tomando una decisión o analizando un problema, siempre arrancamos preguntándonos qué es lo mejor para el cliente y de ahí trabajamos hacia atrás.
context: Lenny asks Bill to explain the concept of 'working backwards' and how it differs from working forwards. Bill describes Amazon's core philosophy of customer obsession, explaining that they believed as an article of faith that prioritizing customer needs would ultimately drive business success. This belief informed their decision-making process of starting with customer problems rather than business constraints.
vocabulary_highlights: took it as an article of faith, come backward from there

speaker: Bob Baxley
text: I just seek out opportunities to witness history. The whole company is constantly asking how can the thing that I'm working on be a little bit better?
text_ko: 저는 그냥 역사를 직접 목격할 기회를 찾아요. 회사 전체가 제가 맡은 일이 어떻게 조금이라도 더 나아질 수 있을지 항상 묻고 있어요.
text_zh: 我就是喜欢找机会见证历史时刻。整个公司上下都在不断地问一个问题：我手头做的这个事儿怎么能再做得好一点？
text_es: Solo busco oportunidades para ser testigo de la historia. Toda la empresa se pregunta constantemente: ¿cómo puede ser un poquito mejor esto en lo que estoy trabajando?
context: Lenny asks Bob why he decided to join Apple. Bob explains his motivation for seeking out historically significant opportunities and describes Apple's culture of continuous improvement. He emphasizes how everyone at Apple, regardless of their role, maintains a mindset focused on incremental betterment of their work - from major products to small details like the patented pizza boxes in their cafeteria.
vocabulary_highlights: seek out opportunities, witness history

speaker: Bob Baxley
text: It wasn't a successful stint at Pinterest. I just bounced off the culture. I came in thinking I was supposed to behave the way I behaved at Apple, which is very direct, fighting hard.
text_ko: 핀터레스트에서의 경험은 성공적이지 못했어요. 회사 문화랑 잘 안 맞았어요. 애플에서처럼 아주 직설적이고 강하게 맞서며 일해야 한다고 생각하고 들어갔거든요.
text_zh: 我在Pinterest那段时间不太成功。我跟那里的企业文化就是合不来。我刚去的时候以为应该像在苹果时那样做事，就是很直接，该争的时候使劲争。
text_es: No fue una etapa exitosa en Pinterest. Simplemente no encajé con la cultura de la empresa. Llegué pensando que tenía que comportarme como lo hacía en Apple, que es muy directo, luchando fuerte por las ideas.
context: Bob openly discusses his unsuccessful experience at Pinterest, explaining how cultural differences between companies can lead to poor fits. He describes how he tried to apply Apple's very direct, intense communication style at Pinterest, where the culture was different. This illustrates the challenge of transitioning between companies with strong but different organizational cultures.
vocabulary_highlights: bounced off the culture, fighting hard

speaker: Bob Baxley
text: I've never seen somebody graft it on after the fact. It's there at the beginning in the root DNA or doesn't exist. Saying a company is design-led does not mean it's designer-led.
text_ko: 사후에 억지로 끼워 넣는 걸 본 적이 없어요. 처음부터 뿌리 DNA(root DNA)에 있거나 아예 없는 거예요. 회사를 디자인 주도(design-led)라고 하는 게 곧 디자이너 주도(designer-led)라는 뜻은 아니에요.
text_zh: 我从没见过有人能后来再硬塞进去的。这东西要么一开始就在公司的基因里，要么就是没有。说一个公司是设计驱动的，不等于说它是设计师主导的。
text_es: Nunca he visto a nadie que logre injertarlo después. O está ahí desde el principio, en el ADN de la empresa, or simplemente no existe. Decir que una empresa está orientada al diseño no significa que esté dirigida por diseñadores.
context: Bob explains his philosophy about design culture in companies. He argues that truly design-centric companies must have design thinking embedded from their founding - it cannot be added later. He also clarifies an important distinction: a company can prioritize design thinking and methodology without necessarily being led by people with designer titles.
vocabulary_highlights: graft it on after the fact, root DNA, design-led does not mean designer-led

speaker: Bob Baxley
text: Almost everyone living in a modern economy now is going to have hundreds of interactions with a phone or with a computer. And unfortunately, a lot of those interactions are not going to be great. We have an obligation as product people to put that emotional energy back into people's lives.
text_ko: 현대 경제에 사는 거의 모든 사람들은 이제 휴대폰이나 컴퓨터와 수백 번씩 상호작용해요. 안타깝게도 그중 많은 상호작용이 별로 좋지 않을 거예요. 프로덕트 담당자(product people)로서 우리는 그 감정적 에너지(emotional energy)를 사람들의 삶에 다시 불어넣어야 할 책임이 있어요.
text_zh: 现在生活在现代经济环境下的人，基本上每天都要跟手机或电脑打几百次交道。但说实话，这里面很多体验都挺糟心的。我们做产品的人有责任把那种积极的情感体验重新带回到大家的生活中去。
text_es: Casi todo el mundo que vive en una economía moderna hoy en día va a tener cientos de interacciones con el teléfono o con la computadora.
