Y desafortunadamente, muchas de esas interacciones no van a ser buenas. Como gente de producto, tenemos la obligación de devolverle esa energía emocional a la vida de las personas.
context: Bob makes a compelling argument about the moral responsibility of people who build digital products. He points out that in today's world, people have countless daily interactions with software and technology, and many of these experiences are frustrating or confusing. He believes product creators have a duty to improve these interactions and restore positive emotional energy to users' lives.
vocabulary_highlights: put that emotional energy back

speaker: Bob Baxley
text: Design is trying to imagine the future you want to live in and then take the steps to make it real. It's living with a certain type of intentionality in almost a Buddhist type way, which is different from science, which is observational trying to understand.
text_ko: 디자인은 자신이 살고 싶은 미래를 상상하고 그걸 현실로 만들기 위해 실제로 한 걸음씩 행동하는 과정이에요. 거의 불교적인 방식처럼 일종의 '의도적인 삶(intentionality)'을 사는 거고요, 이 점에서 세상을 관찰해서 이해하려는 과학과는 달라요.
text_zh: 设计就是要去想象你想要的未来生活，然后一步步把它变成现实。这其实是一种很有目的性的生活方式，有点像佛教那种mindfulness(正念)的感觉，跟科学不一样——科学更多是通过观察去理解世界。
text_es: El diseño es intentar imaginar el futuro en el que quieres vivir y luego dar los pasos para hacerlo realidad. Es vivir con cierto tipo de intencionalidad, casi de manera budista, que es diferente de la ciencia, que es observacional y trata de entender.
context: Lenny asks Bob for his unique perspective on what design actually is. Bob provides a philosophical definition that goes beyond visual aesthetics. He describes design as a forward-looking mindset focused on creating desired future states, contrasting it with other disciplines like science (which observes to understand) and engineering (which solves step-by-step problems).
vocabulary_highlights: living with a certain type of intentionality

speaker: Bob Baxley
text: When design thinking became big, I was always really confused because I didn't know how else you could think. That was just how I naturally thought, which is design is trying to imagine the future you want to live in and then take the steps to make it real.
text_ko: 디자인 씽킹(design thinking)이 유행했을 때 저는 정말 혼란스러웠어요. 다른 식으로 생각할 수 있다는 걸 몰랐으니까요. 그건 원래 제 자연스러운 사고 방식이었고, 제게 디자인은 살고 싶은 미래를 상상하고 그걸 현실로 만들기 위해 한 걸음씩 실천해 나가는 거예요.
text_zh: 当设计思维(design thinking)火起来的时候，我特别纳闷，因为我不知道还能怎么想问题。这就是我天生的思维方式嘛——设计就是要想象你想要的未来生活，然后一步步把它变成现实。
text_es: Cuando el design thinking se puso de moda, siempre me quedé muy confundido porque no sabía de qué otra manera se podía pensar. Así era como yo pensaba naturalmente, o sea, que el diseño trata de imaginar el futuro en el que quieres vivir y luego dar los pasos para hacerlo realidad.
context: Bob reflects on the popular concept of 'design thinking' that became trendy in business circles. He explains his confusion about treating design thinking as a special methodology, since to him, this forward-looking, intentional approach to problem-solving was simply his natural way of thinking. This reveals how some people intuitively approach challenges with a design mindset.
vocabulary_highlights: didn't know how else you could think

speaker: Bob Moesta
text: The moment you stop making progress in your career is the moment you start looking for another job. And so over the last 15 years we've interviewed over a thousand people. I've coached almost a thousand people because I think there's a billion people a year who switched jobs and ultimately most of them end up with a job that's worse than the one they were at, but they don't know how to find it. They don't know themselves well enough.
text_ko: 경력에서 더는 발전이 없다고 느끼는 순간 사람들은 바로 다른 일자리를 알아보기 시작해요. 그래서 지난 15년 동안 저희는 천 명이 넘는 분들을 인터뷰했고, 거의 천 명가량을 코칭했어요. 저는 매년 약 10억 명이 이직한다고 보는데, 결국 그들 대부분은 이전보다 못한 직장으로 가는 경우가 많아요. 그 이유는 좋은 자리를 찾는 방법을 모르고, 자신을 충분히 잘 모르기 때문이에요.
text_zh: 当你在职场上不再有进步的时候，就该开始找下一份工作了。所以过去15年里，我们面试了上千个人，我也指导过将近一千个人，因为我觉得全世界每年有十亿人在跳槽，但最终大部分人找到的工作其实还不如原来那份，可他们不知道怎么去找合适的工作，说白了就是对自己了解得不够深。
text_es: El momento en que dejas de crecer profesionalmente es cuando empiezas a buscar otro trabajo. Y mira, en estos últimos 15 años hemos entrevistado a más de mil personas. Yo he asesorado a casi mil personas porque creo que hay mil millones de personas al año que cambian de trabajo y al final la mayoría termina en un puesto peor que el que tenían, pero no saben cómo encontrar el indicado. No se conocen lo suficientemente bien a sí mismas.
context: Lenny asks Bob about the big idea behind his new book called Job Moves. Bob explains that he spent 15 years researching why people switch jobs and discovered that most people end up in worse positions than they started. The core problem he identifies is that people struggle with job transitions because they lack self-awareness about what they truly want and need in their careers.
vocabulary_highlights: switched jobs, end up with, worse than the one they were at, don't know themselves well enough

speaker: Bob Moesta
text: It's very similar to product. There's difference between product features and product experiences, and what you start to realize is it's the experiences that keep you at your job. It's not just about the money because you start to realize money is a surrogate for respect, or I've got bills to pay or I'm falling behind. Money has actually many, many different implications to it because everybody wants more money, but the question is why do you want more money?
text_ko: 이건 제품하고 굉장히 비슷해요. 제품 기능(product features)과 제품 경험(product experiences)은 다르고, 점점 깨닫게 되는 건 결국 여러분을 직장에 머물게 하는 건 기능이 아니라 경험이라는 거예요. 단순히 돈 때문만은 아니에요. 돈이 존중의 대용물(surrogate for respect)이거나, ‘청구서 내야 해서’나 ‘뒤처질까 봐’ 같은 이유로 여겨지기도 해요. 돈에는 사실 아주 다양한 의미가 있어요. 누구나 더 많은 돈을 원하지만, 중요한 건 왜 더 원하느냐는 질문이에요.
text_zh: 这和做产品很像。产品功能(product features)和产品体验(product experiences)是两回事，你慢慢就会发现，真正让你留在一份工作的是那种体验感。不光是钱的问题，因为你会意识到钱其实代表的是尊重，或者说我得还房贷车贷，或者我觉得自己落后了。钱这个东西其实有很多很多层含义，每个人都想要更多钱，但问题是你为什么想要更多钱？
text_es: Es muy parecido con los productos. Hay una diferencia entre las características de un producto y las experiencias que te da ese producto, y lo que te das cuenta es que son las experiencias las que te mantienen en tu trabajo. No se trata solo del dinero porque te das cuenta de que el dinero es como un sustituto del respeto, o "tengo cuentas que pagar" o "me estoy quedando atrás". El dinero en realidad tiene muchísimas implicaciones diferentes porque todo mundo quiere más dinero, pero la pregunta es ¿por qué quieres más dinero?
context: Lenny asks Bob about the distinction between job features like salary and title versus job experiences. Bob draws a parallel to product development, explaining that just as product experiences matter more than features, job experiences are what actually retain employees. He argues that money is often a surrogate for deeper needs like respect or security, and understanding the 'why' behind wanting more money is crucial.
vocabulary_highlights: surrogate for, I've got bills to pay, falling behind, many different implications

speaker: Bob Moesta
text: When you're in a startup, it changes who you are and the moment that you get out of that environment, you need to take the time to reset your mind and your body. I call it a jobcation, which is a job I can go do with one hand tie by hide my back so I can rest and recover to go do something else. It's about actually being able to go to the gym and work out and have some vacations. The moment you are comfortable doing nothing, you know who you are again, and you can actually figure this out.
text_ko: 스타트업(startup)에 있으면 사람 자체가 달라져요. 그 환경에서 벗어나면 정신과 몸을 재정비할 시간을 꼭 가져야 해요. 저는 그걸 잡케이션(jobcation)이라고 부르는데, 한 손이 묶여 있어도 해낼 수 있을 정도로 부담이 적고 쉬면서 회복해 다음 일을 할 수 있게 해주는 일이에요. 사실 그건 헬스장에 가서 운동도 하고, 휴가도 제대로 보내는 걸 말해요. 아무것도 안 하는 것에 편안해지는 순간에야 자신이 누구인지 다시 알게 되고, 어떻게 해야 할지 진짜로 알 수 있어요.
text_zh: 在创业公司干活的时候，整个人都会变，一旦脱离那种环境，你得花时间让自己的身心都缓过来。我管这叫"工作式休假"(jobcation)，就是找个闭着眼睛都能干的轻松活儿，让自己能喘口气，恢复元气，好去做下一件事。其实就是能真正去健身房锻炼锻炼，度个假什么的。当你能舒舒服服地什么都不干的时候，你就又找回自己了，这样才能想明白接下来该怎么办。
text_es: Cuando estás en una startup, te cambia completamente como persona, y en el momento que sales de ese ambiente, necesitas darte tiempo para resetear tu mente y tu cuerpo. Yo le digo "jobcation" - un trabajo que puedo hacer con una mano atada atrás de la espalda para poder descansar y recuperarme antes de hacer algo más. Se trata de poder ir al gym, hacer ejercicio, tomarte unas vacaciones de verdad. En el momento que te sientes cómodo sin hacer nada, ahí vuelves a saber quién eres realmente, y ahí sí puedes resolver las cosas.
context: Lenny mentions Bob's concept of a 'jobcation' from the book. Bob explains that after intense startup experiences, people need time to reset and recover their true identity. A jobcation is an easier, less demanding job that allows someone to rest, exercise, and reconnect with themselves. He emphasizes that being comfortable with doing nothing is key to rediscovering your authentic self.
vocabulary_highlights: with one hand tie by hide my back, rest and recover, comfortable doing nothing

speaker: Bob Moesta
text: One of the things we do in the book, so it's nine steps for you to basically go through. And the reality is I would tell you, I'm not sure anybody's going to do all nine steps, but the fact is this is like if you're going to do this, this is the best of the best, but if you do five of the steps, you're going to actually be way better off. So it's like I don't want to intimidate people by nine steps, but the reality is this is a really big one, which is to go back through your career and even back to college, I've taken people back to high school and basically talk about those moments where you got energy, you walked into a situation and you literally were like, "Oh my God, I got so excited about this and why did I get excited?"
text_ko: 책에서 우리가 하는 것 중 하나는 기본적으로 여러분이 따라가게끔 아홉 단계로 정리해 놓은 거예요. 솔직히 말하면 아홉 단계를 전부 다 하실 분이 많을지는 잘 모르겠어요. 그런데 이건 만약 하신다면 최고의 방법이고, 설령 다섯 단계만 해도 훨씬 나아질 거예요. 아홉 단계라고 사람들을 겁주고 싶진 않아요. 실제로 정말 중요한 한 가지는 경력을 거꾸로 되짚어 보는 건데요, 대학 때로, 심지어 제가 사람들을 고등학교 시절까지 데려가서 그때 그 순간들을 이야기하곤 해요—어떤 상황에 들어갔을 때 에너지가 확 솟으면서 “와, 진짜 신난다, 왜 이렇게 신났지?”라고 느꼈던 순간들을요.
text_zh: 我们在这本书里设计了九个步骤让大家去走一遍。说实话，我觉得可能没人会把九个步骤全做完，但这就像是，如果你真想做好这件事，这就是最好的方法了。不过呢，哪怕你只做其中五个步骤，也会比现在好很多。我不想用九个步骤把大家吓跑，但有一个步骤真的特别重要，就是回顾一下你的职业生涯，甚至回到大学时代，我甚至带一些人回到高中时期，去想想那些让你特别有劲儿的时刻，你走进某个情况的时候会想"天哪，这个太让我兴奋了"，然后问问自己为什么会这么兴奋。
text_es: Una de las cosas que hacemos en el libro es que te damos nueve pasos para seguir. Y la realidad es que te voy a ser honesto, no creo que nadie vaya a hacer los nueve pasos completos, pero el punto es que si vas a hacer esto bien, esto es lo mejor de lo mejor. Pero si haces cinco de los pasos, ya vas a estar muchísimo mejor. O sea, no quiero que la gente se asuste por los nueve pasos, pero la realidad es que hay uno que es clave, que es revisar toda tu carrera profesional e incluso regresar hasta la universidad - he llevado a gente hasta la preparatoria - y básicamente hablar de esos momentos donde te llenaste de energía, donde llegaste a una situación y literalmente dijiste "¡Ay, Dios mío, esto me emocionó un montón!" y preguntarte por qué te emocionó tanto.
context: Lenny asks Bob for advice on figuring out what gives you energy versus what drains your energy. Bob explains his comprehensive nine-step process from the book, but reassures that doing even five steps will be beneficial. He describes the key exercise of reflecting on past career moments that generated excitement and energy, going as far back as high school or college to identify patterns of what truly energizes you.
vocabulary_highlights: the best of the best, way better off, intimidate people, Oh my God

speaker: Bob Moesta
text: The first thing I would do is I would actually look at the job description and unpack what you mean by things. Get it down to what are the... So, for example, they'll say five years experience. What I will tell you is that's one of the worst statements you can put on any job like recruiting thing because why five years? What is it about? What this to me is a sign that you're lazy because you're saying, oh, you need to have five years experience. For an entry entry-level job, how does that work? What do you really need to know?
text_ko: 먼저 제가 할 일은 직무 기술서(job description)를 실제로 꼼꼼히 들여다보고, 거기 적힌 표현들이 정확히 무슨 의미인지 하나하나 풀어보는 거예요. '진짜로 필요한 게 뭔지'로 좁혀서 정리하라는 뜻이죠. 예를 들어 '경력 5년'이라고 쓰는 경우가 많은데, 솔직히 그건 채용 공고(recruiting posting)에 넣기 가장 안 좋은 문구 중 하나예요. 왜 굳이 5년인가요? 그 기간이 어떤 능력을 의미하나요? 제겐 그게 '그냥 귀찮아서 대충 쓴 것'으로 보이는 신호예요. 신입(entry-level) 채용에 그게 어떻게 적용되죠? 실제로 어떤 지식이나 능력이 필요한지 구체적으로 적어야 해요.
text_zh: 我首先会做的就是仔细看看这个职位描述，搞清楚你们到底想要什么。把它拆解成具体的要求... 比如说，他们会写"需要五年工作经验"。我跟你说，这是招聘里最烂的表述之一，为什么非得是五年？这五年到底要干什么？在我看来，这就是偷懒的表现，就是随便写个"需要五年经验"。这还是个入门级岗位，这怎么搞？你们真正需要的到底是什么？
text_es: Lo primero que haría sería revisar bien la descripción del puesto y desglosar qué quieren decir realmente con cada cosa. Llegar al fondo de... Por ejemplo, van a poner "cinco años de experiencia". Te voy a decir algo: esa es una de las peores frases que puedes poner en cualquier proceso de reclutamiento porque ¿por qué cinco años? ¿De qué se trata exactamente? Para mí esto es señal de que están siendo flojos porque están diciendo "ah, necesitas cinco años de experiencia". Para un puesto de entrada, ¿cómo funciona eso? ¿Qué es lo que realmente necesitas saber?
context: Lenny asks Bob for advice on hiring better people. Bob criticizes common job description practices, particularly the arbitrary requirement of 'five years experience.' He argues this is lazy recruiting because it doesn't specify what knowledge or skills those five years should have provided. He advocates for being more specific about what you actually need someone to know rather than using vague experience requirements.
vocabulary_highlights: unpack what you mean, one of the worst statements, sign that you're lazy, how does that work

speaker: Bob Moesta
text: Here's the thing is job descriptions should really be, here's the context we're in. Here's what this role is about. Here's what progress means in this role and here's how we will actually reward you for actually doing this work. And it's just not that way. And so again, I'm working on another extension of this book around just helping companies implement this. And so it's so fascinating. It's like it's a thread that just keeps pulling. I keep pulling.
text_ko: 사실 중요한 건 직무 설명서(job descriptions)가 정말로 '우리가 처한 맥락(context)이 무엇인지, 이 역할(role)이 어떤 일인지, 이 역할에서의 진전(progress)이 무엇을 의미하는지, 그리고 실제로 이 일을 해줬을 때 어떻게 보상(reward)할지'를 알려줘야 한다는 거예요. 그런데 현실은 전혀 그렇지 않아요. 그래서 저는 이 책의 확장판을 하나 더 작업하면서 기업들이 이걸 실제로 적용하도록 돕는 일을 하고 있어요. 정말 흥미로워요. 이건 계속해서 끌리는 실타래 같아서 자꾸만 더 당기게 돼요.
text_zh: 问题是这样的，职位描述(job description)应该是这么写的：这是我们现在的情况，这个岗位是做什么的，在这个岗位上怎么算是有进步，还有我们会怎么奖励你把这个工作做好。但现实不是这样的。所以我又在写这本书的续集，就是专门帮公司落地这些东西。特别有意思，就像抽丝剥茧一样，越挖越深，根本停不下来。
text_es: Mira, la cosa es que las descripciones de trabajo deberían ser más como: "Te explico el contexto en el que estamos, de qué va este puesto, qué significa crecer en este rol y cómo te vamos a reconocer realmente por hacer bien el trabajo". Pero no es así para nada. Y por eso estoy trabajando en otra extensión de este libro para ayudar a las empresas a implementar esto. Es fascinante, ¿sabes? Es como un hilo del que sigo tirando, no puedo parar.
context: Bob is discussing how job descriptions should be written to better attract and match candidates. He outlines what an ideal job description should contain: context about the company situation, role purpose, definition of progress, and reward structure. He notes that current job descriptions don't follow this format, which has inspired him to work on helping companies implement better hiring practices.
vocabulary_highlights: here's the context we're in, it's a thread that just keeps pulling

speaker: Bob Moesta
text: I think one of the biggest misconceptions around Jobs to Be Done is this notion that it's pain and gain as opposed to context and outcome. When you hear somebody's story and it seems irrational, like we'll have people go, "Oh my God, that's an anomaly. That doesn't happen." But what you realize is that the context makes the irrational rational.
text_ko: 제가 보기에는 고객이 해결하려는 과제(Jobs to Be Done, JTBD)에 대해 가장 큰 오해 중 하나가 이걸 고통과 이득(pain and gain)으로만 보는 거예요. 사실은 맥락(context)과 결과(outcome)에 관한 건데요. 누군가의 이야기를 듣고 비합리적으로 느껴지면 사람들은 “세상에, 그건 예외야. 그런 일이 일어나지 않아”라고 말하죠. 그런데 알고 보면 그 사람의 맥락이 있으면 겉으로 비합리적으로 보이는 행동도 충분히 합리적이에요.
text_zh: 我觉得关于"待完成任务"(Jobs to Be Done)最大的误解之一，就是大家总认为这是关于痛点和收益，而不是情境和结果。当你听到某个人的故事，觉得很不合理的时候，就会有人说"天哪，这是个例外情况，不可能的。"但你会发现，正是那个具体情境让看似不合理的事情变得合理了。
text_es: Creo que uno de los mayores malentendidos sobre Jobs to Be Done es pensar que se trata de dolor y beneficio en lugar de contexto y resultado. Cuando escuchas la historia de alguien y parece ilógica, la gente dice "Ay, Dios mío, eso es una anomalía. Eso no pasa." Pero lo que te das cuenta es que el contexto hace que lo ilógico tenga sentido.
context: Lenny asks Bob about common misconceptions people have about the Jobs to Be Done framework. Bob explains that many people incorrectly focus only on pain points and benefits when analyzing customer behavior, rather than understanding the full context surrounding customer decisions. He emphasizes that what appears to be irrational customer behavior usually makes perfect sense when you understand the complete situational context that drove their decision.
vocabulary_highlights: misconceptions, pain and gain, anomaly, irrational rational

speaker: Bob Moesta
text: But it's not just the pain. See, what we're taught in business school was pain and gain, but the reality is it's the context. It's not that I'm in pain, but it's the context that makes me value this in the moment that much more than something else. And so part of this is it's not just about pain and gain, it's about context and outcomes.
text_ko: 근데 문제는 단순히 고통(pain)만 있는 게 아니에요. 보세요, 비즈니스 스쿨에서는 '고통과 이득(pain and gain)'이라고 가르치지만, 실제로는 맥락(context)이 더 중요한 경우가 많아요. 제가 아프다거나 하는 게 아니라, 그 상황의 맥락 때문에 지금 이걸 다른 것보다 훨씬 더 가치 있게 느끼는 거예요. 그래서 요점은 단순히 고통과 이득이 아니라 맥락(context)과 결과(outcomes)에 있다는 거예요.
text_zh: 但这不仅仅是痛点的问题。你看，商学院教我们的是痛点和收益(pain and gain)，但现实情况是要看具体环境。不是说我有什么痛点，而是当下的环境让我觉得这个东西比其他的更有价值。所以关键在于，这不只是痛点和收益的问题，而是要看具体情况和最终结果。
text_es: Pero no se trata solo del dolor. Mira, lo que nos enseñan en las escuelas de negocios era dolor y ganancia (pain and gain), pero la realidad es que todo depende del contexto. No es que esté sufriendo, sino que es el contexto lo que me hace valorar esto en este momento mucho más que cualquier otra cosa. Entonces parte de esto es que no se trata únicamente de dolor y ganancia, sino de contexto y resultados.
context: Lenny challenges Bob about how Jobs to Be Done differs from simply looking for customer pain points, which most founders claim they already do. Bob clarifies that the framework goes beyond identifying pain - it requires understanding the specific situational context that makes customers value one solution over another at a particular moment. He explains this creates a "vector of progress" that helps companies understand true customer motivation.
vocabulary_highlights: pain and gain, context and outcomes, vector of progress

speaker: Bob Moesta
text: But here's the other part is that there's this waterline that there's these other forces. Every time I show somebody something new, it actually creates anxiety, right? Anxiety of the new, and I call this F3. And then the other thing is I have to get them to leave old thing. So I call this habit of the present.
text_ko: 그리고 또 한 가지는, 수면선(waterline) 같은 경계 아래에서 다른 힘들이 작용한다는 점이에요. 누군가에게 새로운 걸 보여줄 때마다 사실 불안이 생겨요 — 새로움에 대한 불안이죠. 저는 이걸 F3라고 부릅니다. 그리고 또 하나는 그들이 기존의 방식을 떠나게 만들어야 한다는 거예요. 저는 그걸 '현재의 습관(habit of the present)'이라고 불러요.
text_zh: 但是还有另一个方面，就是有个水位线，有其他一些力量在起作用。每次我给别人展示新东西的时候，实际上都会产生焦虑，对吧？对新事物的焦虑，我把这个叫做F3。然后另一个问题是，我得让他们放弃旧的东西。所以我把这个叫做当下的习惯(habit of the present)。
text_es: Pero mira, aquí está la otra parte: hay como una línea bajo el agua donde actúan otras fuerzas. Cada vez que le muestro algo nuevo a alguien, en realidad les genera ansiedad, ¿no? La ansiedad de lo nuevo, y a esto yo le llamo F3. Y luego está la otra cosa: tengo que lograr que dejen lo viejo. A esto le digo el hábito del presente.
context: Lenny asks Bob to explain the "vector" concept in more detail. Bob draws a diagram showing four forces that influence customer behavior: F1 (push from current situation), F2 (pull toward new outcome), F3 (anxiety about the new solution), and F4 (habit of staying with current solution). He explains that customers will only change when the push and pull forces exceed the anxiety and habit forces - this "waterline" concept helps companies understand why customers don't switch even when presented with better options.
vocabulary_highlights: waterline, anxiety of the new, habit of the present
topics: Product Management, Strategy & Planning, Decision Making

speaker: Bob Moesta
text: The very first thing I would say is I never trust anybody telling me things they're going to do because they can't assure it, and it usually never happens. So the phrase I have 'Bitchin' ain't switchin'.' Just because people bitch about something doesn't mean they're going to do anything about it.
text_ko: 먼저 말씀드리자면, 누군가 '이렇게 하겠다'고 말하면 저는 잘 믿지 않아요. 확실히 약속할 수 없고, 보통 결국 안 하더라고요. 그래서 제가 자주 하는 말이 '불평한다고 바뀌진 않아요'(Bitchin' ain't switchin')예요. 불평만 한다고 누가 행동으로 옮기지는 않아요.
text_zh: 我首先要说的是，我从来不相信别人跟我说他们要做什么事，因为他们根本没法保证，而且通常都不会真的去做。所以我有句话叫"光抱怨没用"。就是说人们虽然对某件事各种抱怨，但这不代表他们真的会采取什么行动。
text_es: Lo primero que diría es que nunca le creo a nadie cuando me dice las cosas que va a hacer, porque no pueden garantizarlo, y por lo general nunca pasa. Entonces tengo una frase: "Quejarse no es cambiar." El hecho de que la gente se queje de algo no significa que vayan a hacer algo al respecto.
context: Lenny asks how to distinguish between customers who complain but won't actually switch versus those who will genuinely adopt a new solution. Bob explains that customer intentions about future behavior are unreliable - people often say they'll switch but don't follow through. His phrase "Bitchin' ain't switchin'" captures this insight that complaints don't predict actual behavior change. He emphasizes studying people who have already made changes rather than those who say they will.
vocabulary_highlights: Bitchin' ain't switchin'

speaker: Bob Moesta
text: The method itself is not based on traditional research or market research, asking people what it is. It's actually based on criminal and intelligence interrogation about telling me the story about how you decided today's the day I bought a house or today's the day I went back to school. It's not random.
text_ko: 이 방법 자체는 전통적인 조사나 시장조사(market research)처럼 사람들에게 그게 뭔지 단순히 묻는 방식이 아니에요. 사실은 범죄 수사나 정보기관 심문(criminal and intelligence interrogation)에서 쓰이는 방식에 기반해서, 사람들이 “오늘 왜 집을 사기로 했는지”나 “오늘 왜 학교로 돌아가기로 결심했는지” 같은 결정을 내리게 된 이야기를 말하게 하는 거예요. 즉, 그건 우연히 일어나는 게 아니에요.
text_zh: 这个方法本身不是基于传统的调研或市场调研，问人家这个那个的。它实际上是基于刑侦和情报审讯的套路，就是让你跟我讲故事——你是怎么决定"今天就是我买房的日子"或者"今天就是我重新上学的日子"。这可不是随便问问的。
text_es: El método en sí no se basa en investigación tradicional o estudios de mercado, preguntándole a la gente qué es lo que quiere. En realidad se basa en técnicas de interrogatorio criminal y de inteligencia para que me cuentes la historia de cómo decidiste que "hoy es el día que compro una casa" o "hoy es el día que regreso a estudiar". No es algo al azar.
context: Lenny asks about the difference between what customers say they want versus what they actually purchase. Bob explains that his Jobs to Be Done approach uses interview techniques borrowed from criminal and intelligence interrogation rather than traditional market research surveys. Instead of asking hypothetical questions about preferences, he focuses on getting detailed stories about actual purchase decisions, emphasizing that customer behavior follows causal patterns rather than being random.
vocabulary_highlights: criminal and intelligence interrogation, not random

speaker: Bob Moesta
text: There's three levels of information we have to get or three sources of energy that I talk about. There's what I call functional energy, which is usually time, space, effort, knowledge, right? There's emotional energy, which is how I feel. And then there's social aspects, how I want others to perceive me or how others perceive me.
text_ko: 제가 말하는 정보의 레벨이나 에너지 원천이 세 가지 있어요. 첫 번째는 제가 '기능적 에너지(functional energy)'라고 부르는 건데, 보통 시간, 공간, 노력, 지식 같은 것들이에요. 두 번째는 '감정적 에너지(emotional energy)'로, 내가 어떻게 느끼는지에 관한 거예요. 그리고 세 번째는 '사회적 측면(social aspects)'인데, 다른 사람들이 나를 어떻게 보길 원하는지 또는 실제로 어떻게 보는지에 관한 거예요.
text_zh: 我们要获取的信息有三个层面，或者说我讲的三种能量来源。第一种我叫功能性能量(functional energy)，通常就是时间、空间、精力、知识这些，对吧？第二种是情感能量(emotional energy)，就是我的感受如何。第三种是社交层面的，就是我希望别人怎么看我，或者别人实际上是怎么看我的。
text_es: Mira, hay tres niveles de información que tenemos que conseguir, o tres fuentes de energía de las que hablo. Está lo que yo llamo energía funcional, que normalmente es tiempo, espacio, esfuerzo, conocimiento, ¿verdad? Está la energía emocional, que es cómo me siento. Y luego están los aspectos sociales, cómo quiero que otros me perciban o cómo me perciben los demás.
context: Lenny asks for tactical advice on how to start implementing Jobs to Be Done. Bob recommends interviewing recent customers about their purchase decisions and explains that successful interviews must capture three types of energy that drive customer behavior. Functional energy involves practical constraints like time and effort, emotional energy covers feelings and frustrations, and social energy relates to how customers want to be perceived by others. Understanding all three energy sources provides complete insight into customer motivation.
vocabulary_highlights: functional energy, emotional energy, social aspects

speaker: Andrew 'Boz' Bosworth
speaker_expertise: Product Management, AI/ML Products, Engineering Leadership
text: I don't want to take away from the romanticism of it, it's just that it's most often we hear those romantic stories from the successes. It's a healthy thing for people to want to throw themselves into something and take that risk, but it is not glamorous at the time.
text_ko: 그 낭만성을 없애고 싶은 건 아니에요. 다만 그런 낭만적인 이야기들은 대개 성공한 사람들 얘기에서만 들리곤 해요. 어떤 일에 몸을 던지고 위험을 감수하려는 건 건강한 마음이에요. 다만 그 순간에는 사실 그렇게 멋져 보이진 않아요.
text_zh: 我不是想破坏创业的浪漫色彩，只是我们听到的那些浪漫故事大多都来自成功的案例。人们愿意全身心投入、承担风险是好事，但真正经历的时候一点都不光鲜。
text_es: No quiero quitarle lo romántico al asunto, es solo que casi siempre escuchamos esas historias románticas de los que la pegaron. Está muy bien que la gente se quiera aventar de lleno a algo y arriesgarse, pero en el momento no es nada glamoroso.
context: Lenny asks Boz about the early days at Facebook, noting that movies like The Social Network make starting a company look fun and glamorous. Boz explains that while those early startup days created great memories and camaraderie, they were forged through intense hardship - working 120 hours per week, gaining weight, having no social life, and constantly dealing with technical crises. He emphasizes that people only hear these romantic startup stories from the companies that succeeded, not from those who made similar sacrifices but didn't achieve success.
vocabulary_highlights: romanticism, throw themselves into, glamorous at the time

speaker: Andrew 'Boz' Bosworth
speaker_expertise: Product Management, AI/ML Products, Engineering Leadership
text: Your job is not to do it yourself. Your job is to get it done, is to have the thing done, done well, done right, done competently. And a lot of times, the tools that you need to do that live with your manager, with your partner, with your advisor, with your mentor.
text_ko: 당신의 일은 직접 다 해내는 게 아니에요. 당신의 역할은 일이 끝나게 하는 거예요. 일이 잘, 제대로, 능숙하게 마무리되도록 만드는 것이요. 그리고 그런 걸 위해 필요한 도구들은 매니저나 파트너, 어드바이저, 멘토 같은 사람들에게 있는 경우가 많아요.
text_zh: 你的工作不是什么事都亲力亲为。你的工作是把事情搞定，而且要做好、做对、做得专业。很多时候，你需要的资源和支持都在你的老板、合作伙伴、顾问或者导师那里。
text_es: Tu trabajo no es hacerlo tú mismo. Tu trabajo es lograr que se haga, que la cosa quede bien hecha, hecha como debe ser, hecha de manera competente. Y muchas veces, las herramientas que necesitas para conseguirlo las tiene tu jefe, tu socio, tu asesor, tu mentor.
context: Lenny discusses Boz's popular advice about leveraging leaders more effectively. Boz explains that people often want to prove they can solve problems independently, but this misses the point of their actual job responsibilities. He argues that the goal isn't to demonstrate personal capability by working alone, but to achieve the best possible outcomes using all available resources - including the expertise, connections, and authority that managers and mentors possess.
vocabulary_highlights: done competently, live with your manager

speaker: Andrew 'Boz' Bosworth
speaker_expertise: Product Management, AI/ML Products, Engineering Leadership
text: Nobody wants you to be more awesome than your manager does, because when you're amazing, your manager, his life gets easier, her life gets easier. So, I just think that's the mentality we get into is like, 'No, no, no. They're testing me.' They're not. They are rooting for you.
text_ko: 사실 상사는 당신이 더 능력 있어지길 바라요. 당신이 잘하면 상사의 삶도 훨씬 편해지거든요. 그래서 우리는 ‘아니야, 아니야, 상사가 나를 시험하고 있어’라고 생각하게 되는데, 그건 오해예요. 그분들은 당신을 응원하고 있어요.
text_zh: 没有人比你的老板更希望你牛逼了，因为你要是干得特别棒，你老板的日子就好过多了。所以我觉得咱们不要总想着"不对不对，他们在考验我"，其实不是的，他们是在为你加油打气呢。
text_es: Nadie quiere que seas más exitoso que tu jefe, porque cuando tú la rompes, a tu jefe se le hace la vida más fácil. Entonces, creo que la mentalidad que tenemos es como "No, no, no. Me están poniendo a prueba." Pero no es así. Ellos están de tu lado.
context: Boz continues explaining why people should ask their managers for help more often. He uses an analogy from actor Patrick Stewart about auditions - casting directors want actors to succeed because it makes their job easier once they find the right person. Similarly, Boz argues that managers genuinely want their employees to excel because employee success directly makes the manager's work easier and more effective.
vocabulary_highlights: rooting for you, the mentality we get into

speaker: Andrew 'Boz' Bosworth
speaker_expertise: Product Management, AI/ML Products, Engineering Leadership
text: We've turned that on its head, and it sounds great, but it's not free. Even somebody senior coming from outside of the company to the company, one of the things I have to coach them on is, how do you find signal amongst all the noise?
text_ko: 우리는 그걸 완전히 뒤집어 놨고, 듣기엔 멋지지만 공짜는 아니에요. 외부에서 영입된 시니어 분들도 제가 꼭 코치하는 것 중 하나는, 수많은 잡음(noise) 속에서 의미 있는 신호(signal)를 찾아내는 방법이에요.
text_zh: 我们把这个完全颠倒过来了，听起来很棒，但这不是没有代价的。就算是从外面招进来的高管，我也得教他们一个事儿：怎么在这么多杂音里找到真正有用的信息？
text_es: Nosotros le dimos la vuelta a eso completamente, y suena genial, pero no sale gratis. Incluso cuando llega alguien con experiencia de fuera de la empresa, una de las cosas en las que tengo que orientarlos es: ¿cómo encuentras la señal entre tanto ruido (signal vs. noise)?
context: Lenny asks about Meta's culture of extreme transparency, where employees can ask executives questions directly and all data is shared openly. Boz explains that while most companies carefully curate what information employees receive, Meta gives access to almost everything and expects employees to filter it themselves. This creates tremendous empowerment but requires people to develop sophisticated systems for managing information overload and distinguishing important updates from irrelevant noise.
vocabulary_highlights: turned that on its head, not free, find signal amongst all the noise

speaker: Andrew 'Boz' Bosworth
speaker_expertise: Product Management, AI/ML Products, Engineering Leadership
text: Now News Feed was an easier case than people suspect, because everyone was outraged at the same time as they immediately doubled their usage of the product.
text_ko: 뉴스 피드(News Feed)는 사람들이 생각하는 것보다 더 쉬운 사례였어요. 모두가 분노했지만 동시에 그 서비스를 즉시 두 배로 사용했거든요.
text_zh: 其实动态消息(News Feed)比大家想的要好处理，因为所有人一边骂得要死，一边使用频率直接翻了一倍。
text_es: Mira, el News Feed fue un caso más fácil de lo que la gente piensa, porque aunque todos estaban súper molestos, al mismo tiempo duplicaron el uso del producto de un día para otro.
context: Lenny asks about building the Facebook News Feed, which was highly controversial when it launched but became essential to what people think of as Facebook today. Boz explains that while users were vocally angry about the new feature, their behavior told a different story - they were refreshing and using the product much more frequently. This created a clear signal that there was cognitive dissonance between what users said they wanted versus their revealed preferences through actual usage patterns.
vocabulary_highlights: easier case than people suspect, doubled their usage

speaker: Andrew 'Boz' Bosworth
speaker_expertise: Product Management, AI/ML Products, Engineering Leadership
text: When I reflect back on what really worked across my career, it really comes down to this: I just was willing to learn aggressively. I would move because I wasn't learning enough. I was bored, and so I wasn't learning enough new stuff.
text_ko: 돌아보면 제 커리어에서 진짜로 통했던 건 결국 이거였어요: 배우는 데 매우 적극적이었어요. 배울 게 충분하지 않다고 느끼면 자리를 옮겼고, 지루해지면 그건 곧 새로운 걸 충분히 배우지 못하고 있다는 신호였어요.
text_zh: 回头想想我职业生涯中真正有效的东西，其实就是这么回事：我特别愿意去学新东西，学得很猛。如果我觉得学不到什么了，我就会换地方。因为我会觉得无聊，学不到新玩意儿。
text_es: Cuando miro hacia atrás en lo que realmente funcionó en mi carrera, todo se reduce a esto: simplemente tenía las ganas de aprender a full. Me cambiaba de trabajo porque no estaba aprendiendo lo suficiente. Me aburría, y por eso no estaba aprendiendo cosas nuevas.
context: Lenny asks about career advice, particularly regarding how much time to spend on different types of projects. Boz reflects on his unusual career path at Meta, where he changed roles every six months early on while his peers stayed in single tracks and got promoted faster initially. He explains that his willingness to keep moving to learn new things eventually paid off dramatically when he finally found roles deep enough to sustain his learning for years, leading to rapid vertical career growth.
vocabulary_highlights: learn aggressively, wasn't learning enough new stuff

speaker: Andrew 'Boz' Bosworth
speaker_expertise: Product Management, AI/ML Products, Engineering Leadership
text: Communication is the job is, I really believe... whenever something goes wrong, I ask myself, 'What could I have done differently in terms of how I communicated things for this to have gone better?'
text_ko: 저는 소통 자체가 업무의 핵심이라고 정말 믿어요. 무언가 잘못될 때마다 스스로에게 "이 상황이 더 잘 풀리려면 내가 소통을 어떻게 달리했어야 했을까?"라고 물어봐요.
text_zh: 沟通就是工作本身，我是真的这么认为的...每当出什么问题的时候，我都会问自己，'在沟通方面，我要是换个方式说，事情会不会处理得更好？'
text_es: La comunicación es realmente el trabajo, yo creo firmemente que... cada vez que algo sale mal, me pregunto: '¿Qué pude haber hecho diferente en cuanto a cómo comuniqué las cosas para que esto hubiera salido mejor?'
context: Lenny asks Boz to explain his famous post 'Communication is the Job.' Boz argues that if you want to have any impact on the world around you, it happens exclusively through communication - creating artifacts or verbalizations that affect other humans. He practices extreme ownership by always examining his own communication when things go wrong, rather than blaming others for misunderstanding or poor execution.
vocabulary_highlights: extreme ownership

speaker: Brandon Chu
text: What we do have is an annual planning cycle basically, we call investment plans and it's for fairly large SWOTs to the organization. I'm talking like 20% chunks of all of Shopify consolidated under a VP here and there to put forward a vision for what that team's going to accomplish that year, whether that is a directional change or even specific outcomes in some cases.
text_ko: 우리가 가지고 있는 건 연간 계획 주기인데, 이걸 투자 계획이라고 부르거든요. 이건 조직에 꽤 큰 SWOT(강점, 약점, 기회, 위협) 분석을 포함해요. 예를 들어, Shopify 전체의 20% 정도를 차지하는 팀들이 VP 아래에서 그 해에 어떤 목표를 달성할지를 제시하는 거예요. 방향성을 바꾸는 경우도 있고, 특정 결과를 목표로 하는 경우도 있어요.
text_zh: 我们有个年度规划流程，基本上叫投资计划(investment plans)，主要针对组织里比较大的业务板块做SWOT分析。我说的是那种占整个Shopify大概20%体量的部门，由各个VP负责，让他们提出愿景，说明这个团队那一年要完成什么目标，不管是战略方向的调整还是具体的业务结果。
text_es: Lo que sí tenemos es básicamente un ciclo de planificación anual, le decimos planes de inversión y es para análisis FODA (SWOTs) bastante grandes para la organización. Te hablo de como pedazos del 20% de todo Shopify consolidado bajo un VP por aquí y por allá para presentar una visión de lo que ese equipo va a lograr ese año, ya sea un cambio de rumbo o incluso resultados específicos en algunos casos.
context: Lenny asks about Shopify's framework or process for making bigger decisions. Brandon explains their annual planning cycle where VPs create investment plans for large portions of the organization. Each investment plan covers about 20% of Shopify's workforce under a VP and outlines what that team will accomplish that year, whether through directional changes or specific outcomes.
vocabulary_highlights: fairly large SWOTs, consolidated under, put forward a vision, directional change

speaker: Brandon Chu
text: But what's really amazing and also difficult about Shopify though is we're pretty good at never falling into sunk-cost fallacy. So we'll throw it all away anytime if the world changes. And so that's why it's actually a really tricky place for a lot of folks because there are cases and it's happened to me many times where it's just like you're building three, six months into something and it's just not important anymore or the world changed.
text_ko: 하지만 Shopify가 정말 놀랍기도 하고 또 어려운 점은, 매몰비용 오류(sunk-cost fallacy)에 거의 빠지지 않는다는 거예요. 세상이 바뀌면 언제든 다 접어버려요. 그래서 많은 사람들한테는 여기 분위기가 꽤 까다로워요. 저도 그런 경우를 여러 번 겪었는데, 3~6개월 동안 뭘 열심히 만들어 놨더니 어느 순간 더 이상 중요하지 않거나 세상이 변해버리곤 해요.
text_zh: 不过Shopify真正厉害但也挺难的地方在于，我们从来不会陷入沉没成本的陷阱(sunk-cost fallacy)。只要世界变了，我们随时都能把之前做的全部推倒重来。所以对很多人来说，这地方确实不好待，因为经常会出现这种情况——我自己就遇到过好多次——你花了三个月、六个月在做一个项目，结果突然就不重要了，或者整个大环境都变了。
text_es: Pero lo que realmente impresiona y también es complicado de Shopify es que somos bastante buenos para nunca caer en la falacia del costo hundido (sunk-cost fallacy). O sea, botamos todo a la basura cuando sea necesario si el mundo cambia. Y por eso es que en realidad es un lugar bien difícil para mucha gente, porque hay casos - y me ha pasado muchísimas veces - donde llevas tres, seis meses construyendo algo y de repente ya no importa o el mundo cambió.
context: Brandon continues explaining Shopify's decision-making approach, highlighting how they avoid the sunk-cost fallacy. Sunk-cost fallacy is when people continue investing in something because they've already spent resources on it, even when it's no longer the best option. He explains that Shopify is willing to abandon projects even after months of work if circumstances change, which can be challenging for employees but keeps the company agile.
vocabulary_highlights: sunk-cost fallacy, throw it all away, really tricky place

speaker: Brandon Chu
text: I think what I learned over the arc of my career is that especially when it comes to product management specifically, it's a lot of the hard skills that PMs are known for, so organizational, analytical, good communication, even technical skills. There's sort of table stakes and commodities to be an entry level PM.
text_ko: 제가 커리어를 쌓으면서 배운 건, 특히 프로덕트 매니지먼트(product management) 분야는 조직력, 분석력, 좋은 의사소통, 심지어 기술적 역량 같은 하드 스킬(hard skills)이 대부분이라는 거예요. 다시 말해 초급 PM(entry-level PM)이 되기 위한 건 기본 요건(table stakes)이자 흔한 자질들(commodities)이에요.
text_zh: 我觉得在我整个职业生涯中学到的是，特别是在产品管理(product management)这个领域，很多PM(product manager)需要具备的硬技能，比如组织能力、分析能力、沟通能力，甚至是技术能力，这些其实都是入门级PM的基本门槛，算是标配了。
text_es: Creo que lo que he aprendido a lo largo de mi carrera es que, especialmente en gestión de productos, muchas de las habilidades duras por las que se conoce a los PMs —como la organización, el análisis, la buena comunicación, incluso las habilidades técnicas— son como el mínimo indispensable, lo básico que necesitas para ser un PM junior.
context: Lenny asks Brandon for advice on what helped him achieve his impressive career trajectory at Shopify that newer PMs could learn from. Brandon explains that traditional PM hard skills like organization, analysis, and communication are just the baseline requirements for entry-level PM roles. He's setting up to explain what skills are needed to advance beyond that level.
vocabulary_highlights: over the arc of my career, table stakes, commodities

speaker: Brandon Chu
text: But I think ultimately to have the highest trajectory and what certainly was a tailwind for my career was you guys have to lean into those founder skills. And so things like being a great storyteller, how to get the most out of people around you, foster creative and motivated teams and know how to make really, really hard high conviction decisions that actually can't be solved.
text_ko: 결국 제 커리어에 가장 큰 도움이 됐던 건, 여러분이 바로 그런 창업가적 역량(founder skills)에 적극적으로 기대고 발휘해야 한다는 점이에요. 훌륭한 스토리텔러(storyteller)가 되는 법, 주변 사람들로부터 최대한의 성과를 이끌어내는 법, 창의적이고 동기 부여된 팀을 만들고 키우는 법, 그리고 사실상 해결책이 없는 것처럼 보이는 정말 어려운 문제들에 대해 확신을 갖고 결단하는 법(high conviction decisions)을 아는 것들이요.
text_zh: 但我觉得最终要想有最好的发展轨迹，对我职业生涯真正起到推动作用的，还是得发挥那些创始人的核心能力。比如说要会讲故事，知道怎么激发身边人的潜力，打造有创造力、有干劲的团队，还有就是面对那些没有标准答案的难题时，能做出坚定的决策。
text_es: Pero creo que al final, para tener la trayectoria más alta y lo que definitivamente fue un impulso para mi carrera fue que tienen que apostar fuerte por esas habilidades de fundador. O sea, cosas como ser un gran contador de historias (storyteller), cómo sacar lo mejor de la gente que te rodea, crear equipos creativos y motivados, y saber tomar decisiones súper difíciles con total convicción, esas que realmente no se pueden resolver con fórmulas.
context: Brandon continues his advice about advancing as a PM beyond entry-level skills. He identifies 'founder skills' as the key differentiator for high career trajectory. These include storytelling abilities, getting the best performance from team members, fostering creativity and motivation, and making difficult decisions with strong conviction even when there's no clear analytical solution.
vocabulary_highlights: highest trajectory, tailwind for my career, lean into, high conviction decisions

speaker: Brandon Chu
text: Oh, it's honestly been the most important thing I've ever done in my career unbelievably. And it's had probably two really interesting effects. One is that as Shopify grew and when we were going through hyperscale, you probably recognize this from your Airbnb days as well but people are falling from the sky.
text_ko: 정말 솔직히 말하면 제 경력에서 했던 일 중 가장 중요한 일이었어요, 믿기 힘들 정도로요. 그리고 그게 아마 두 가지 정말 흥미로운 효과를 가져왔어요. 하나는 Shopify가 성장하고 우리가 하이퍼스케일(hyperscale)을 겪을 때인데, 아마 에어비앤비 다니시던 시절에도 느끼셨겠지만 사람들이 하늘에서 떨어지듯 쏟아져 들어왔어요.
text_zh: 说实话，这真的是我职业生涯中做过的最重要的事情，重要到难以置信。而且产生了两个特别有意思的效果。第一个就是随着Shopify的发展，当我们进入超高速增长期的时候，你从Airbnb的经历应该也深有体会，就是人才像天上掉下来一样多。
text_es: Oye, honestamente ha sido lo más importante que he hecho en mi carrera, increíblemente. Y ha tenido probablemente dos efectos súper interesantes. Uno es que mientras Shopify crecía y cuando estábamos pasando por una hiperescala (hyperscale), seguramente te suena de tus días en Airbnb también, pero la gente nos llovía del cielo.
context: Lenny asks Brandon about the impact writing has had on his career. Brandon describes writing as the single most important thing for his career success. He explains that during Shopify's rapid growth phase (hyperscale), new employees were joining constantly - he uses the vivid expression 'people are falling from the sky' to describe how quickly new hires were arriving and needing onboarding and context.
vocabulary_highlights: hyperscale, people are falling from the sky

speaker: Brandon Chu
text: So I actually found that writing externally and getting momentum externally was a better way to influence internally what was happening, to the effect that Tobi would read my post here and there and he'd be like, 'Great post.' And I'd be like, 'Hey, daddy loves me.'
text_ko: 그래서 사실 저는 외부에서 글을 쓰고 모멘텀(momentum)을 얻는 게 내부에서 벌어지는 일에 더 큰 영향을 준다는 걸 알게 됐어요. 그래서 토비가 가끔 제 글(post)을 읽고 '좋은 글이야'라고 하면 저는 '아빠가 날 좋아하네' 싶었어요.
text_zh: 所以我发现，对外写文章、在外面建立影响力，反而是影响内部决策更好的方式。托比会时不时看到我的文章，然后跟我说"写得不错"，我心里就想"哎呀，老大认可我了"。
text_es: Resulta que me di cuenta de que escribir para audiencias externas y generar tracción afuera era una mejor forma de influir internamente en lo que pasaba en la empresa. O sea, Tobi leía mis posts de vez en cuando y me decía "Excelente post", y yo quedaba como "Ay, papá me quiere."
context: Brandon explains how his external writing helped him gain influence within Shopify's chaotic, fast-growing environment. With so much happening internally, it was difficult to get the attention of 200+ PMs for new ideas. He discovered that publishing content externally and gaining traction outside the company was more effective for influencing internal decisions. When Tobi (Shopify's CEO) would praise his posts, it built his credibility and trust within the organization.
vocabulary_highlights: getting momentum externally, to the effect that, daddy loves me

speaker: Brandon Chu
text: Everyone has so many different backgrounds, but I'd say overall, based on most PMs that I've met, I'd say, look, it is hard to do when you are a PM somewhere, but do a legitimate side hustle, found a company on the side and learn everything else. Because I think sometimes you're in this silo of your feature, your area or whatnot.
text_ko: 사람들 배경은 정말 다양하지만, 제가 만난 대부분의 프로덕트 매니저들(PMs)을 보면 한마디로 말하면, PM으로 일할 때는 하기 어렵지만 진짜 제대로 된 부업(side hustle)을 해보거나 옆에서 회사를 창업(found a company)해서 다른 것들을 모두 배워보라고 권하고 싶어요. 왜냐하면 가끔은 자기 담당 기능(feature)이나 영역에만 갇혀 있게 되거든요.
text_zh: 每个人的背景都不一样，但是从我接触过的大部分产品经理来看，我觉得吧，虽然你当PM(产品经理)的时候确实挺难的，但还是要搞点正经的副业，在业余时间创个公司，学学其他方面的东西。因为我觉得有时候你就困在自己那个功能、自己那块地盘里了。
text_es: Mira, todos vienen de trasfondos muy diferentes, pero por lo que he visto con la mayoría de PMs que conozco, te diría: oye, sé que es complicado cuando ya trabajas como PM en algún lado, pero métete en un proyecto paralelo de verdad, monta una empresa aparte y aprende todo lo demás. Porque creo que a veces te quedas muy encerrado en tu funcionalidad, en tu área o lo que sea.
context: Lenny asks Brandon for one piece of advice for PMs to level up in their careers. Brandon recommends starting a legitimate side business or founding a company while working as a PM. He explains that PMs often get trapped in a narrow focus on their specific feature or product area, missing the broader perspective of what it takes to build and run a complete business.
vocabulary_highlights: legitimate side hustle, in this silo

speaker: Brendan Foody
text: The wealthiest companies in the world are willing to spend whatever it takes to improve model capabilities. The market is bound by the amount of things where humans can do something that models can't. The lab's primary bottleneck to improve models is how they can effectively have some way of measuring what success looks like for the model.
text_ko:
세계에서 가장 부유한 기업들은 모델 역량(model capabilities)을 높이기 위해 필요한 건 뭐든지 투자할 준비가 돼 있어요.  
시장 규모는 사람이 모델이 못 하는 일을 할 수 있는 영역의 크기에 의해 제한돼요.  
랩(lab)의 모델 개선에서 가장 큰 병목은 모델의 성공이 어떤 모습인지 효과적으로 측정할 방법을 마련하는 거예요.
text_zh: 全世界最有钱的那些公司，为了提升模型能力，花多少钱都舍得。市场的天花板就看人类能做而模型做不了的事情还有多少。实验室要改进模型，最大的卡脖子问题就是怎么有效衡量模型到底做得成功不成功。
text_es: Las empresas más prósperas del mundo están dispuestas a invertir lo que sea necesario para mejorar las capacidades de sus modelos. El mercado está limitado por la cantidad de tareas donde los humanos pueden hacer algo que los modelos no pueden. El principal cuello de botella (bottleneck) del laboratorio para mejorar los modelos es cómo pueden tener una manera efectiva de medir cómo se ve el éxito del modelo.
context: Lenny asks Brendan why the AI training data market has become so valuable and why companies like Mercor are experiencing unprecedented growth. Brendan explains that AI labs are facing a fundamental bottleneck - they need ways to measure and evaluate model performance across different capabilities. Since the most advanced AI companies have virtually unlimited resources to improve their models, they're willing to pay premium rates for experts who can help them assess what success looks like for their AI systems.
vocabulary_highlights: whatever it takes, bound by, primary bottleneck
topics: Product Management, Strategy & Planning, Growth & Marketing

speaker: Brendan Foody
text: If the model is the product, then the eval is the product requirement document. And reinforcement learning is becoming so effective that once they have an eval, they can help climb it. If you look at just how fast people were able to saturate Olympiad Math once they focused on it, how fast we're even saturating SWE-bench once we focus on it.
text_ko: 모델(model)이 제품이라면, 평가(eval)는 제품 요구사항 문서(product requirement document)와 같아요. 강화학습(reinforcement learning)이 워낙 효과적이라 일단 평가가 마련되면 그 평가를 바탕으로 성능을 끌어올리는 데 바로 활용할 수 있어요. 사람들이 올림피아드 수학(Olympiad Math)에만 집중했을 때 얼마나 빠르게 포화에 이르렀는지, 우리도 SWE-bench(SWE-bench)에 집중하면 얼마나 빨리 포화시키는지 보면 그게 잘 드러나요.
text_zh: 如果模型就是产品，那评测(eval)就相当于产品需求文档(PRD)。现在强化学习(reinforcement learning)变得特别厉害，只要有了评测标准，就能帮着往上冲。你看奥数竞赛，大家一认真搞，很快就刷到头了；还有SWE-bench那个基准测试，我们一专注去做，也很快就要刷满分了。
text_es: Si el modelo es el producto, entonces la evaluación es el documento de requisitos del producto. Y el aprendizaje por refuerzo se está volviendo tan efectivo que una vez que tienen una eval, pueden ayudar a escalarla. Si ves qué tan rápido la gente pudo saturar las Olimpiadas de Matemáticas una vez que se enfocaron en eso, qué tan rápido estamos saturando incluso el SWE-bench una vez que nos enfocamos en ello.
context: Lenny asks Brendan to explain what the "era of evals" means and why evaluations are becoming so important in AI development. Brendan uses an analogy to explain that evaluations (evals) serve the same purpose for AI models that product requirement documents serve for traditional products - they define what success looks like. He explains that once labs have clear evaluation criteria, they can use reinforcement learning techniques to rapidly improve model performance on those specific tasks.
vocabulary_highlights: climb it, saturate, focus on it

speaker: Brendan Foody
text: What everyone is generally moving towards is reinforcement learning from AI feedback instead of human feedback where you have instead the human defined some sort of success criteria, some way to measure that. And it's far more scalable and data-efficient, and so that's why a lot of the broader trend in the market across the board is moving towards RLHF to both eval models as well as improved capabilities.
text_ko: 요즘 대부분이 향하는 방향은 사람이 직접 평가하는 인간 피드백 대신 AI가 주는 피드백으로부터 학습하는 강화학습(reinforcement learning from AI feedback)이에요. 예전에는 사람이 어떤 성공 기준을 정해 그걸로 성과를 측정했죠. 그런데 AI 기반 방식이 훨씬 더 확장 가능하고 데이터 효율적이라서, 시장 전반에서 모델 평가와 성능 개선 모두에 AI 피드백 기반 강화학습(reinforcement learning from AI feedback, 기존 RLHF 개념의 확장) 쪽으로 움직이고 있어요.
text_zh: 现在大家普遍都在往一个方向走，就是用AI反馈来做强化学习(reinforcement learning)，而不是用人的反馈。这种方式是让人先定义好成功的标准，定义好怎么去衡量。这样做扩展性更强，数据效率也更高，所以你看市场上整体的大趋势都在朝RLHF这个方向发展，既能用来评估模型，也能提升模型的能力。
text_es: Hacia donde se está moviendo todo el mundo en general es el aprendizaje por refuerzo con retroalimentación de IA en lugar de retroalimentación humana, donde lo que tienes es que el humano define algún tipo de criterio de éxito, alguna forma de medirlo. Y es mucho más escalable y eficiente en cuanto a datos, por eso es que gran parte de la tendencia general en el mercado está yendo hacia RLHF tanto para evaluar modelos como para mejorar capacidades.
context: Lenny asks Brendan to explain what experts are actually doing when they work with AI labs. Brendan describes the evolution of AI training methods, explaining how the industry is shifting from human-driven feedback to AI-driven feedback systems. In this newer approach, humans create the success criteria and rubrics, but AI systems handle the actual evaluation and feedback process, making the training process much more efficient and scalable.
vocabulary_highlights: data-efficient, across the board

speaker: Brendan Foody
text: It's highly likely that the entire economy will become an aural environment machine, building out all of these worlds and contexts. And I think the narrative in AI over the last three years has almost entirely been one of job displacement, but very few companies and people have talked about this new category of jobs that's being created.
text_ko: 전체 경제가 이런 세계와 맥락을 전부 구현해 나가는 청각 기반 환경 플랫폼(aural environment machine)이 될 가능성이 커요. 그리고 제 생각엔 지난 3년간 AI 관련 논의는 거의 대부분 일자리 대체(job displacement)에만 집중돼 왔는데, 새로 생겨나는 일자리 카테고리(category of jobs)에 대해 말하는 회사나 사람은 거의 없었어요.
text_zh: 很可能整个经济都会变成一个听觉环境机器，构建出各种各样的世界和场景。我觉得过去三年关于AI的说法几乎都是在讲工作会被取代，但很少有公司和人谈到AI其实在创造一个全新的就业类别。
text_es: Es muy probable que toda la economía se convierta en una máquina de entornos auditivos (aural environment machine), desarrollando todos estos mundos y contextos. Y creo que la narrativa en IA durante los últimos tres años ha sido casi completamente sobre el desplazamiento laboral (job displacement), pero muy pocas empresas y personas han hablado de esta nueva categoría de trabajos que se está creando.
context: Lenny shares a provocative tweet about humans being put on Earth to create training data for AI labs and asks Brendan what this means. Brendan explains his vision that the economy will increasingly involve creating virtual environments and evaluation systems for AI training. He argues that while most discussion about AI focuses on job displacement, there's insufficient attention paid to the entirely new categories of jobs being created in the AI training and evaluation space.
vocabulary_highlights: aural environment machine, narrative, category of jobs

speaker: Brendan Foody
text: I think it's people that can leverage AI to do whatever their day-to-day workflows are. We'll give people interviews where we say, 'Use ChatGPT and Kodak. Use Claude code. Use whatever tool cursor and whatever tools are available to build a website and let's see what product you're able to build in an hour.'
text_ko: 제 생각에는 일상적인 업무 흐름( workflow)을 AI로 잘 활용할 수 있는 사람이 중요해요. 면접에서는 '챗GPT(ChatGPT)랑 코닥(Kodak)을 쓰세요. 클로드 코드(Claude code)를 쓰세요. 커서(Cursor)나 사용 가능한 다른 도구들을 아무거나 써서 웹사이트를 만들어 보고, 한 시간 안에 어떤 제품을 만들 수 있는지 보여주세요.'라고 말할 거예요.
text_zh: 我觉得关键是那些能用AI来处理日常工作流程的人。我们面试的时候会跟候选人说，"你用ChatGPT也好，用Claude写代码也行，什么cursor工具啊，随便什么工具都可以，给你一个小时搭个网站，看看你能做出什么产品来。"
text_es: Creo que son las personas que pueden aprovechar la IA para hacer sus tareas del día a día. Les damos entrevistas donde les decimos: "Usa ChatGPT y Kodak. Usa Claude code. Usa cualquier herramienta como cursor y las que tengas disponibles para armar un sitio web y veamos qué producto puedes crear en una hora."
context: Lenny asks Brendan what skills young people should focus on developing given the rapid changes in AI. Brendan emphasizes that the most valuable skill is learning to effectively use AI tools to enhance productivity in any field. He gives an example of how his company now conducts interviews - instead of testing people's ability to work without AI, they provide access to all available AI tools and evaluate what candidates can accomplish with them.
vocabulary_highlights: leverage, day-to-day workflows

speaker: Brendan Foody
text: I think the most important thing is looking at the leading indicators in fast-moving markets. What matters a ton is actually figuring out what are the new markets, the new pockets of demand that are changing very quickly where the wealthiest customers in the world are willing to pay whatever it takes to improve model capabilities, and how do we focus on the leading indicators of those markets.
text_ko: 저는 가장 중요한 건 빠르게 변화하는 시장(fast-moving markets)에서 선행 지표(leading indicators)를 보는 거라고 생각해요. 핵심은 세계에서 가장 부유한 고객들이 모델 성능(model capabilities)을 개선하기 위해 얼마든지 비용을 지불할 의향이 있는, 아주 빠르게 변하는 새로운 시장과 수요의 영역(pockets of demand)이 무엇인지 파악하고, 그 시장들의 선행 지표에 어떻게 집중할지 결정하는 거예요.
text_zh: 我觉得最关键的是要盯住快速变化市场里的先行指标(leading indicators)。真正重要的是要搞清楚哪些是新兴市场，哪些是需求变化特别快的新领域，那些全世界最有钱的客户愿意不惜代价来提升模型能力，我们怎么把注意力放在这些市场的先行指标上。
text_es: Creo que lo más importante es fijarse en los indicadores adelantados (leading indicators) en mercados que se mueven súper rápido. Lo que realmente importa un montón es descifrar cuáles son los nuevos mercados, esos nuevos nichos de demanda que están cambiando a toda velocidad, donde los clientes con más recursos del mundo están dispuestos a pagar lo que sea para mejorar las capacidades del modelo, y cómo nos enfocamos en los indicadores adelantados de esos mercados.
context: Lenny asks Brendan what core tenets contributed to building the fastest-growing company in history. Brendan explains that success in rapidly evolving markets requires focusing on leading indicators rather than lagging metrics. He emphasizes identifying emerging market opportunities where customers have urgent, high-value needs and are willing to pay premium prices - exactly what happened with AI labs needing expert evaluation services.
vocabulary_highlights: leading indicators, pockets of demand, whatever it takes

speaker: Bret Taylor
text: I had realized this subconscious limiter that was limiting my success in the job, which is, I was trying to conform the job to the things I thought I liked to do. So, I was spending a lot of my time on some product and technology things that I was passionate about, thinking I'm the boss. I should focus on what I want to focus on instead of thinking about, okay, I'm running the mobile and platform teams at Facebook. What's the most important thing to do today to make our mobile and developer platform successful?
text_ko: 제가 그동안 직무에서의 성공을 가로막는 무의식적인 한계를 깨달았어요. 그게 뭐냐면, 제가 좋아한다고 생각한 일에 맞춰서 일을 꾸미려고 했던 거예요. 그래서 제품(product)이나 기술(technology) 같은, 제가 열정 있는 분야에 많은 시간을 쓰면서 ‘나는 보스니까 하고 싶은 걸 해야지’라고 생각했죠. 하지만 진짜로 했어야 할 건 ‘나는 페이스북에서 모바일(mobile)·플랫폼(platform) 팀을 운영하고 있는데, 오늘 우리 모바일과 개발자 플랫폼(developer platform)을 성공시키려면 가장 중요한 일이 뭘까?’를 먼저 고민하는 것이었어요.
text_zh: 我意识到有个潜意识里的限制因素在阻碍我的工作成功，就是我总想把工作往我喜欢做的事情上靠。所以我把大量时间花在一些我很有激情的产品和技术方面，心想我是老板嘛，应该专注于我想关注的东西，而不是去想，好吧，我现在负责Facebook的移动端和平台团队，今天最重要的事情是什么，怎样才能让我们的移动端和开发者平台(developer platform)获得成功？
text_es: Me di cuenta de que tenía esta limitación subconsciente que me estaba frenando en el trabajo - estaba tratando de adaptar el puesto a las cosas que creía que me gustaba hacer. O sea, me la pasaba enfocándome en temas de producto y tecnología que me apasionaban, pensando "soy el jefe, debería concentrarme en lo que a mí me interesa" en lugar de preguntarme "oye, estoy manejando los equipos móviles y de plataforma en Facebook. ¿Qué es lo más importante que tengo que hacer hoy para que nuestra plataforma móvil y de desarrolladores sea exitosa?"
context: Lenny asks Bret about what mindsets have contributed to his success across various roles. Bret shares a story about receiving feedback from Sheryl Sandberg when he was CTO at Facebook, managing over 1,000 people across platform and mobile teams. He explains how he realized he was trying to shape his role around his personal preferences rather than focusing on what the job actually required for success.
vocabulary_highlights: subconscious limiter, conform the job to

speaker: Bret Taylor
text: And when I reframed the job that way, I did different things. And the thing that was the biggest pleasant surprise to me was I liked it. I thought I liked engineering and product, but in fact, when I changed an organization and it turned out to be more successful, I derived a great deal of joy from seeing that success.
text_ko: 그렇게 일을 다시 정의했더니 저는 다른 방식으로 일하게 됐어요. 그리고 제게 가장 기분 좋게 놀라웠던 건, 그 일을 좋아한다는 것이었어요. 전에는 엔지니어링(engineering)과 프로덕트를 좋아한다고 생각했는데, 조직을 바꾸고 그게 더 성공적으로 풀리는 걸 보면서 그 성공에서 큰 기쁨을 느꼈어요.
text_zh: 当我换个角度看这份工作的时候，我做事的方式就完全不一样了。最让我意外惊喜的是，我发现自己竟然很喜欢这样。我原本以为自己喜欢的是工程和产品开发，但实际上，当我改变一个组织，看到它变得更成功的时候，那种成就感给我带来了巨大的快乐。
text_es: Y cuando cambié mi manera de ver el trabajo de esa forma, empecé a hacer las cosas de manera diferente. Y lo que más me sorprendió gratamente fue que me gustó. Yo pensaba que me gustaba la ingeniería y el producto, pero resulta que cuando transformé una organización y esta tuvo más éxito, me dio muchísima satisfacción ver ese éxito.
context: Bret continues explaining how Sheryl Sandberg's feedback changed his approach to leadership at Facebook. After reframing his role to focus on what would make the mobile and platform teams successful rather than just doing what he personally enjoyed, he discovered something unexpected about himself. He realized that his true satisfaction came not from specific activities like engineering, but from having meaningful impact.
vocabulary_highlights: reframed the job, derived a great deal of joy

speaker: Bret Taylor
text: And so, that conversation led to my waking up every morning, sometimes literally, but certainly, in the broadest sets of the words saying, 'What is the most impactful thing I can do today?' And really thinking almost like, if you had an external board of advisors telling you what are the things where if you focus on them, you can maximize the likelihood that what you're trying to achieve will happen?
text_ko: 그래서 그 대화 이후로 저는 매일 아침, 때로는 말 그대로 잠에서 깨자마자, 넓은 의미로는 늘 '오늘 내가 할 수 있는 가장 임팩트를 낼 수 있는 일은 무엇일까?'라고 스스로 묻게 됐어요. 그리고 거의 외부 자문단(external board of advisors)이 '그런 일들에 집중하면 당신이 이루려는 목표가 실현될 가능성을 최대화할 수 있다'고 말해주는 것처럼 생각하곤 했어요.
text_zh: 就是那次对话让我每天早上醒来都会问自己，有时候真的是字面意思上的醒来，但更多时候是从更广的层面上说，"今天我能做的最有影响力的事情是什么？"就像你有一个外部顾问团队在告诉你，你应该把精力放在哪些事情上，这样才能最大化你想要实现目标的可能性，真的就是这样去思考问题。
text_es: Y entonces, esa conversación me llevó a despertarme cada mañana, a veces literalmente, pero desde luego, en el sentido más amplio de la palabra, preguntándome: "¿Qué es lo más impactante que puedo hacer hoy?" Y realmente pensando casi como si tuvieras un consejo externo de asesores diciéndote cuáles son las cosas en las que, si te enfocas, puedes maximizar la probabilidad de que lo que estás tratando de lograr realmente suceda.
context: Bret shares the key lesson he learned from his experience with Sheryl Sandberg's feedback at Facebook. This realization led him to develop a daily practice of asking himself what would be most impactful, rather than defaulting to activities he personally preferred. He suggests thinking about work decisions as if guided by an external board of advisors focused purely on achieving objectives.
vocabulary_highlights: in the broadest sets of the words, maximize the likelihood

speaker: Bret Taylor
text: One of the dangers for founders and product managers, but I think particularly for founders is incorrect storytelling. People don't like my product because of X. And if you tell that to yourself and you tell it to your team, all of a sudden, it goes from being an intuition to being a fact. Well, you better hope you're right because if you orient your strategy around fixing a problem and you're wrong, your company's going to fail.
text_ko: 창업자(founder)와 프로덕트 매니저(product manager)에게, 특히 창업자에게 위험한 것 중 하나는 잘못된 스토리텔링이에요. '사람들이 우리 제품을 X 때문에 안 좋아해'라고 스스로 믿고 그걸 팀에게까지 말해버리면, 직감에 불과하던 게 순식간에 사실로 굳어져요. 그래서 그 말이 맞기를 바랄 수밖에 없는데, 그 문제를 해결하는 쪽으로 전략을 맞춰놓고 그 판단이 틀리면 회사는 망할 수 있어요.
text_zh: 对于创始人和产品经理来说，特别是创始人，有一个很危险的问题就是会编错故事。比如说"用户不喜欢我们产品是因为某某原因"，你要是这么跟自己说，也这么跟团队说，那你的直觉马上就变成了"事实"。你最好祈祷自己是对的，因为如果你围绕着一个错误的问题来制定策略，公司肯定得完蛋。
text_es: Uno de los peligros para los fundadores y product managers, pero creo que especialmente para los fundadores, es contarse la historia equivocada. "A la gente no le gusta mi producto por tal razón." Y si te lo dices a ti mismo y se lo dices a tu equipo, de repente pasa de ser una corazonada a convertirse en un hecho. Más te vale estar en lo cierto porque si orientas tu estrategia a resolver un problema y te equivocas, tu empresa se va al garete.
context: Lenny and Bret are discussing the challenge of accurately identifying what the most impactful work is. Bret warns about a common trap where founders create false narratives about why their product isn't succeeding. He explains how these stories can become accepted as truth within a team, leading to strategies based on incorrect assumptions rather than actual root causes.
vocabulary_highlights: incorrect storytelling, orient your strategy around
topics: Starting a Company, Decision Making, Strategy & Planning

speaker: Bret Taylor
text: And I think one of the skills I think is, it really goes around to do you have a good co-founder? Do you have a good leadership team? If you're a product manager, you're a partner in engineering, you're a partner in marketing, you really want to have very real conversations to ensure that you're actually working on the actual correct thing.
text_ko: 제가 생각하기에 중요한 능력 중 하나는 결국 좋은 공동창업자(co-founder)가 있는지, 좋은 리더십 팀(leadership team)이 있는지 확인하는 거예요. 프로덕트 매니저(product manager)라면 엔지니어링(engineering)이나 마케팅(marketing) 쪽의 파트너(partner)로서 우리가 진짜로 올바른 일을 하고 있는지 확실히 하기 위해 솔직하고 실질적인 대화를 나눠야 해요.
text_zh: 我觉得其中一个关键能力就是，你得有个靠谱的联合创始人，有个给力的领导团队。如果你是产品经理，你跟工程那边的伙伴、市场那边的伙伴，真的要经常坐下来好好聊聊，确保大家做的事儿是对的路子。
text_es: Y creo que una de las habilidades clave es, realmente se trata de si tienes un buen cofundador. ¿Tienes un buen equipo de liderazgo? Si eres product manager, eres socio con ingeniería, eres socio con marketing, realmente necesitas tener conversaciones muy francas para asegurarte de que efectivamente estás trabajando en lo que realmente importa.
context: Bret is explaining how founders can avoid the trap of incorrect storytelling about why their products aren't succeeding. He emphasizes that founders tend to default to solutions in their areas of expertise, so having strong partners and co-founders who can challenge these assumptions is crucial for identifying the real problems that need to be solved.
vocabulary_highlights: very real conversations

speaker: Bret Taylor
text: I think there's three segments of the AI market that will end up fairly meaningful markets and then I'll end with how I think it's going to play out. So first is the frontier model market or foundation model market. I think this will end up the small handful of hyperscalers and really big labs just like the cloud infrastructure as a service market.
text_ko: AI 시장은 결국 꽤 의미 있는 세 가지 부문으로 나뉠 것 같아요. 마지막에는 이게 어떻게 전개될지 제 생각도 정리해 드릴게요. 먼저 프런티어 모델 시장(frontier model market) 또는 파운데이션 모델 시장(foundation model market)이 있고요. 이 부문은 결국 소수의 하이퍼스케일러(hyperscalers)와 아주 큰 연구소들만 남는 구조가 될 것 같아요, 마치 클라우드 인프라 서비스 시장(cloud infrastructure as a service market)처럼요.
text_zh: 我觉得AI市场会分成三个板块，最后都会变成很有意义的市场，然后我再说说我觉得会怎么发展。首先是前沿模型(frontier model)市场，或者叫基础模型(foundation model)市场。我觉得这个市场最后就是少数几个超大规模厂商(hyperscaler)和真正的大实验室在玩，就像现在的云基础设施即服务(infrastructure as a service)市场一样。
text_es: Creo que hay tres segmentos del mercado de IA que van a terminar siendo mercados bastante importantes, y luego termino explicando cómo creo que se va a desarrollar todo esto. Entonces, primero está el mercado de modelos de frontera (frontier models) o modelos fundacionales (foundation models). Pienso que esto va a terminar siendo un puñado pequeño de hyperscalers y laboratorios realmente grandes, igual que pasó con el mercado de infraestructura en la nube como servicio.
context: Lenny asks Bret about where founders should focus in the AI market and what areas to avoid, given his unique perspective from building Sierra and being on OpenAI's board. Bret outlines his framework for understanding the AI market by dividing it into three main segments, starting with the foundation model market which he believes will be dominated by large companies with massive capital requirements.
vocabulary_highlights: hyperscalers

speaker: Bret Taylor
text: The whole market is going to go towards agents. I think the whole market is going to go towards outcomes-based pricing. It's just so obviously the correct way to build and sell software.
text_ko: 시장 전체가 에이전트(agents)와 성과 기반 과금(outcomes-based pricing) 쪽으로 갈 거라고 생각해요. 소프트웨어를 만들고 팔 때 그게 정말 옳은 방식이에요.
text_zh: 整个市场都会朝着智能代理(agents)的方向发展。我觉得整个市场都会转向基于结果的定价模式(outcomes-based pricing)。这显然就是开发和销售软件的正确路子嘛。
text_es: Todo el mercado se va a ir hacia los agentes. Creo que todo el mercado se va a orientar hacia precios basados en resultados. Es que es obviamente la forma correcta de desarrollar y vender software, no hay vuelta de hoja.
context: At the very beginning of the podcast, Lenny introduces Bret by mentioning his various high-level roles including CTO of Meta, co-CEO of Salesforce, and chairman of OpenAI, then asks how he thinks the AI market will play out. Bret gives his bold prediction that the entire software market will shift toward AI agents and a new pricing model based on outcomes rather than traditional software licensing.
vocabulary_highlights: outcomes-based pricing

speaker: Brian Balfour
text: Building a great product is one of those things that's necessary, but not sufficient. And actually the separation is between those that build really great distribution.
text_ko: 훌륭한 제품을 만드는 건 꼭 필요하지만, 그 자체로는 충분하지 않아요. 진짜 중요한 건 훌륭한 유통(distribution)을 만드는 거예요.
text_zh: 打造一款优秀的产品是必要的，但仅仅这样还不够。真正的区别在于那些能够建立出色分销渠道的人。
text_es: Construir un gran producto es una de esas cosas que es necesaria, pero no suficiente. La verdadera diferencia está en aquellos que logran una distribución realmente efectiva.
context: Lenny discusses how growth is changing and asks Brian for insights into product growth. Brian emphasizes that while creating a great product is essential, it is not enough for success. He highlights that the true differentiator lies in the ability to establish excellent distribution channels, which can make or break a startup's success.
vocabulary_highlights: not sufficient, great distribution, separation
topics: Product Management, Growth & Marketing, Starting a Company

speaker: Brian Balfour
text: The cycles seem to be getting shorter and shorter, so you actually have a smaller amount of time to play the game.
text_ko: 주기가 점점 짧아지는 것 같아서, 실제로 게임을 할 수 있는 시간이 줄어드는 것 같아요.
text_zh: 周期似乎越来越短，因此你实际上可用来参与游戏的时间也越来越少。
text_es: Los ciclos parecen estar acortándose, por lo que en realidad tienes menos tiempo para jugar el juego.
context: Lenny inquires about the implications of changing growth channels and platforms. Brian explains that the competitive landscape is evolving rapidly, with cycles of innovation and market adaptation occurring at an accelerated pace. This means companies have less time to capitalize on new opportunities before they become saturated.
vocabulary_highlights: shorter and shorter, play the game, smaller amount of time
topics: Strategy & Planning, Growth & Marketing, Decision Making

speaker: Brian Balfour
text: It ends up being a prisoner's dilemma. Don't trick yourself into thinking that you can't play the game.
text_ko: 결국 이건 죄수의 딜레마(prisoner's dilemma) 같은 거예요. 게임을 할 수 없다고 스스로 속이지 마세요.
text_zh: 这最终成为了囚徒困境（prisoner's dilemma）。不要自欺欺人，以为自己无法参与这场游戏。
text_es: Al final, se convierte en un dilema del prisionero. No te engañes pensando que no puedes participar en el juego.
context: Lenny highlights the risks of missing out on new opportunities, and Brian explains that the situation resembles a prisoner's dilemma, where companies must decide whether to engage with emerging platforms or risk being left behind. He advises that it is crucial for businesses to actively participate in these new channels to meet evolving customer expectations and stay competitive.
vocabulary_highlights: prisoner's dilemma, trick yourself, play the game
topics: Growth & Marketing, Decision Making, Strategy & Planning

speaker: Brian Balfour
text: The key thing for everybody to know is that as new distribution platforms emerge, they follow the same four-step cycle.
text_ko: 모두가 알아야 할 중요한 점은 새로운 유통 플랫폼이 생겨날 때마다 같은 네 단계 사이클을 따른다는 거예요.
text_zh: 每个人都应该知道的是，随着新分销平台的出现，它们遵循相同的四步循环。
text_es: Lo más importante que todos deben saber es que, a medida que surgen nuevas plataformas de distribución, siguen el mismo ciclo de cuatro pasos.
context: Lenny asks Brian to elaborate on the cycles that platforms generally follow. Brian introduces the concept of a four-step cycle that new distribution platforms typically undergo. Understanding this cycle is critical for startups to effectively navigate the competitive landscape and capitalize on new opportunities.
vocabulary_highlights: distribution platforms, four-step cycle, emerge

speaker: Brian Balfour
text: One of the major ways that we always see is that this can happen when new distribution platforms emerge, because when new distribution platforms emerge, startups are usually the fastest to take advantage of them.
text_ko: 새로운 유통 플랫폼이 생기면 스타트업이 가장 빨리 그 기회를 잡는 경우가 많아요. 그래서 이게 자주 일어나는 주요한 방법 중 하나예요.
text_zh: 我们常见的一个主要方式是，当新的分销平台（distribution platforms）出现时，这种情况就会发生，因为新兴的分销平台往往是初创企业（startups）最先利用的机会。
text_es: Una de las principales formas en que esto suele ocurrir es cuando surgen nuevas plataformas de distribución, ya que las startups suelen ser las más rápidas en aprovecharlas.
context: Brian explains that one effective strategy for startups to gain a competitive edge is to leverage new distribution platforms that frequently arise. Startups often have the agility to capitalize on these opportunities faster than established competitors, providing them with a unique advantage in the market.
vocabulary_highlights: major ways, take advantage, emerge
topics: Strategy & Planning, Growth & Marketing, Starting a Company

speaker: Brian Balfour
text: What we see is essentially three groups of folks. We call them the catalysts, the converts, and the anchors.
text_ko: 우리가 보는 사람들은 크게 세 그룹이에요. 우리는 이들을 촉매(catalysts), 전환자(converts), 그리고 고정자(anchors)라고 불러요.
text_zh: 我们看到的本质上是三类人。我们称他们为催化剂（catalysts）、转变者（converts）和支柱（anchors）。
text_es: Lo que observamos son esencialmente tres grupos de personas. Los llamamos los catalizadores, los conversos y los anclajes.
context: Brian discusses the different groups of employees within companies undergoing AI adoption. He categorizes them into catalysts, who lead the charge; converts, who can adapt with guidance; and anchors, who resist change. He emphasizes that understanding these dynamics is crucial for facilitating successful transformations within organizations.
vocabulary_highlights: catalysts, converts, anchors
topics: Coaching & Development, Learning & Growth, Leadership & Management

speaker: Brian Chesky
speaker_expertise: Product Management, Growth Strategy, Leadership Development
text: Way too many founders apologize for how they want to run the company. They find some midpoint between how they want to run a company and how the people they lead want to run the company. That's a good way to make everyone miserable. Because what everyone really wants is clarity.
text_ko: 너무 많은 창업자들이 회사를 운영하는 방식에 대해 사과해요. 그들은 자신이 원하는 방식과 팀원들이 원하는 방식 사이에서 중간점을 찾으려고 해요. 이렇게 하면 모두가 불행해질 수 있어요. 사실 모든 사람이 원하는 건 명확함이에요.
text_zh: 太多创始人对自己想要如何运营公司感到抱歉。他们试图在自己想要的管理方式和团队成员希望的管理方式之间找到一个折中点。这种做法只会让每个人都感到不快。因为大家真正想要的是清晰的方向。
text_es: Demasiados fundadores se disculpan por la forma en que quieren dirigir la empresa. Buscan un punto intermedio entre su visión y la manera en que las personas que lideran desean gestionar la compañía. Esa no es la mejor manera de hacer felices a todos. Lo que realmente todos quieren es claridad.
context: Lenny asks Brian about the challenges founders face in managing their companies. Brian emphasizes that many founders often compromise their vision for how to run a company in order to please their teams, which leads to dissatisfaction and confusion. He argues that clarity in leadership is essential for ensuring that everyone can work towards a common goal effectively.
vocabulary_highlights: midpoint, miserable, clarity

speaker: Brian Chesky
speaker_expertise: Product Management, Growth Strategy, Leadership Development
text: People think that great leader's job is to hire people and just empower them to do a good job. Well, how do you know they're doing a good job if you're not in the details? And so I made sure I was in the details and we really drove the product.
text_ko: 사람들은 훌륭한 리더의 역할이 사람들을 채용하고 그들이 잘 할 수 있도록 지원하는 것이라고 생각해요. 그런데 세부사항을 모르면 그들이 잘 하고 있는지 어떻게 알 수 있을까요? 그래서 저는 세부사항에 신경을 쓰고, 정말로 제품을 이끌어 나갔어요.
text_zh: 人们认为优秀领导者的工作就是招聘人才并赋予他们权力去做好工作。然而，如果你不深入细节，怎么知道他们是否做得好呢？因此，我确保关注细节，并且我们真正推动了产品的发展。
text_es: La gente piensa que el trabajo de un gran líder es contratar personas y simplemente empoderarlas para que hagan un buen trabajo. Sin embargo, ¿cómo sabes si están haciendo un buen trabajo si no estás en los detalles? Por eso me aseguré de estar en los detalles y realmente impulsamos el producto.
context: In response to a question about leadership, Brian discusses the common misconception that leaders should simply hire talented individuals and allow them to work independently. He stresses the importance of leaders being involved in the details of their operations to ensure quality and effectiveness. This hands-on approach helps foster a productive environment.
vocabulary_highlights: empower, in the details, drove the product

speaker: Brian Chesky
speaker_expertise: Product Management, Growth Strategy, Leadership Development
text: The basic idea is this. You can't build a product unless you know how to talk about the product. You can't be an expert in making the product unless you're also an expert in the market of it.
text_ko: 기본적인 아이디어는 이거예요. 제품에 대해 이야기할 줄 모르면 제품을 만들 수 없어요. 그리고 그 제품의 시장에 대한 전문가가 아니면 제품 만드는 전문가가 될 수 없어요.
text_zh: 基本的观点是这样的：如果你不知道如何谈论一个产品，就无法构建这个产品。要成为该产品的专家，你也必须在其市场中具备专业知识。
text_es: La idea básica es esta: no puedes desarrollar un producto a menos que sepas cómo comunicarlo. No puedes ser un experto en la creación del producto si no eres también un experto en su mercado.
context: Lenny inquires about the integration of product management and marketing at Airbnb. Brian explains that understanding both the product and the market is crucial for successful product development. He emphasizes that expertise in one area alone is insufficient; leaders must also be adept at communicating the value of their products to customers.
vocabulary_highlights: expert, talk about, market of it

speaker: Brian Chesky
speaker_expertise: Product Management, Growth Strategy, Leadership Development
text: If you want to improve the speed of a company, then make faster decisions. And fast decisions come from a bias of action.
text_ko: 회사의 속도를 높이고 싶다면, 빠른 결정을 내려야 해요. 그리고 빠른 결정은 행동 편향(bias of action)에서 나와요.
text_zh: 如果想提高公司的运作速度，就要加快决策。而快速决策源于行动的偏向。
text_es: Si deseas mejorar la velocidad de una empresa, entonces toma decisiones más rápidas. Y las decisiones rápidas provienen de un sesgo hacia la acción.
context: Brian shares insights on how to enhance organizational efficiency. He argues that accelerating decision-making processes can significantly improve a company's speed and productivity. He advocates for a culture that encourages quick, decisive actions rather than prolonged deliberations.
vocabulary_highlights: improve the speed, bias of action, decisive

speaker: Brian Chesky
speaker_expertise: Product Management, Growth Strategy, Leadership Development
text: The secret to happiness, if there is one, is healthy relationships. And I had found, Lenny, that over the time of being an entrepreneur, I had gotten totally isolated.
text_ko: 행복의 비밀이 있다면, 그건 건강한 관계라고 생각해요. 그리고 레니, 제가 기업가로 활동하면서 완전히 고립되어 버렸다는 걸 깨달았어요.
text_zh: 如果有幸福的秘诀，那就是健康的人际关系。而我发现，Lenny，作为一名企业家，我在这段时间里变得完全孤立。
text_es: El secreto de la felicidad, si es que existe uno, son las relaciones saludables. Y he descubierto, Lenny, que con el tiempo como emprendedor, me he sentido completamente aislado.
context: In response to a question about avoiding burnout, Brian reflects on the importance of maintaining healthy personal relationships for overall happiness. He reveals how entrepreneurship can lead to isolation and emphasizes the necessity of nurturing connections with friends and loved ones to achieve balance in life.
vocabulary_highlights: secret to happiness, healthy relationships, isolated

speaker: Brian Chesky
speaker_expertise: Product Management, Growth Strategy, Leadership Development
