text: I think the pace of the team is one of the most important things you can do. And that pace is sometimes governed not by how hard people work, but how decisive they are.
text_ko: 팀의 속도가 가장 중요한 요소 중 하나라고 생각해요. 그리고 그 속도는 때때로 사람들이 얼마나 열심히 일하느냐보다는 얼마나 결단력이 있느냐에 따라 결정돼요.
text_zh: 我认为团队的节奏是你能做的最重要的事情之一。而这种节奏有时并不是由人们的工作努力程度决定的，而是由他们的果断程度决定的。
text_es: Creo que el ritmo del equipo es una de las cosas más importantes que puedes lograr. Y ese ritmo a veces no está determinado por cuán duro trabajan las personas, sino por cuán decisivas son.
context: Brian discusses the significance of pace in a team's performance during a conversation about leadership. He suggests that a team's rhythm is influenced more by the decisiveness of its leaders than by the sheer volume of work. This highlights the critical role of leadership in setting the tempo for productivity.
vocabulary_highlights: pace of the team, governed, decisive

speaker: Brian Tolkin
text: Uber always has this mentality and Opendoor does too of like a twin turbine jet plane where you can fly the plane on one engine for a little bit if you need to, but it's operating most efficiently and effectively if both are working together.
text_ko: Uber와 Opendoor는 항상 쌍발 제트기처럼 생각해요. 한쪽 엔진만으로도 잠깐 비행할 수 있지만, 두 개의 엔진이 함께 작동할 때 가장 효율적이고 효과적으로 운영된다는 거죠.
text_zh: Uber 和 Opendoor 都有一种类似双涡轮喷气机的心态，虽然在需要时可以单独使用一台发动机飞行一段时间，但只有当两台发动机协同工作时，才能实现最高的效率和效果。
text_es: Uber siempre tiene esta mentalidad, al igual que Opendoor, de ser como un avión a reacción de doble turbina, donde puedes volar el avión con un motor por un tiempo si es necesario, pero está funcionando de manera más eficiente y efectiva cuando ambos trabajan juntos.
context: Lenny asks Brian about how product and operations teams should work together. Brian uses the metaphor of a 'twin turbine jet plane' to illustrate that both operations and product must function in harmony for optimal efficiency. He emphasizes that operations teams can provide valuable insights that inform product development, highlighting the importance of collaboration between the two functions.
vocabulary_highlights: twin turbine jet plane, operating efficiently, working together

speaker: Brian Tolkin
text: Starting on the operations side gave a really deep understanding of how the business actually works. You are truly operating it day in and day out and the success of the city is in large part driven by the inputs that you are putting into it every single day on the ground.
text_ko: 운영 쪽에서 시작하니까 비즈니스가 실제로 어떻게 돌아가는지 깊이 이해할 수 있었어요. 매일매일 직접 운영을 하니까, 도시의 성공이 여러분이 매일 현장에서 기여하는 부분에 크게 달려 있다는 걸 느끼게 돼요.
text_zh: 从运营方面入手，让我对业务的实际运作有了深入的理解。你每天都在实际操作中，城市的成功在很大程度上取决于你每天在现场投入的努力。
text_es: Comenzar en el área de operaciones me brindó una comprensión profunda de cómo funciona realmente el negocio. Estás operándolo día tras día y el éxito de la ciudad se debe en gran medida a las contribuciones que realizas cada día en el terreno.
context: Lenny inquires about the impact of Brian's operations background on his product leadership. Brian explains that his experience in operations provided him with an intimate understanding of business dynamics, emphasizing that daily decisions and actions significantly influence success. He underscores the value of being close to the customer and understanding on-the-ground operations.
vocabulary_highlights: deep understanding, in large part driven, inputs

speaker: Brian Tolkin
text: I think part of this may have been sharpened in the early days of Uber. Everything felt like a fire drill all the time. So the only way to operate, but I think you almost hit the nail on the head in the question, which is a little bit of an intellectual answer of when you reflect the stress onto your teams, everybody tenses up.
text_ko: 이건 아마 우버 초창기 때의 경험이 영향을 미쳤던 것 같아요. 항상 긴급 상황처럼 느껴졌거든요. 그래서 그렇게 운영할 수밖에 없었죠. 질문에서 거의 핵심을 찔렀다고 생각해요. 스트레스를 팀에 반영하게 되면, 모두가 긴장하게 되니까요.
text_zh: 我认为这部分可能源于Uber早期的日子。那时一切都像是在进行紧急演习。因此，唯一的运作方式就是这样，但我觉得你在提问时几乎抓住了关键，反思压力传递给团队时，大家都会变得紧张。
text_es: Creo que parte de esto puede haberse agudizado en los primeros días de Uber. Todo se sentía como una emergencia constante. Así que la única forma de operar era esa, pero creo que casi diste en el clavo con la pregunta, que es un poco una respuesta intelectual: cuando reflejas el estrés en tus equipos, todos se tensan.
context: Lenny discusses Brian's ability to stay calm under pressure. Brian reflects on his experience during the chaotic early days at Uber, noting that a stressful environment can negatively impact team performance. He shares that maintaining composure is crucial and that leaders should strive to prevent stress from affecting their teams, promoting a more productive atmosphere.
vocabulary_highlights: reflect the stress, tenses up, intellectual answer

speaker: Brian Tolkin
text: If you can really figure out this is really what matters, that's the core part of the job. It dovetails even back to our earlier conversation. In the early days of building tech and ops companies is where's the tech leverage? Same question, where's the kernel of what really matters that tech can uniquely solve?
text_ko: 이게 진짜 중요한 부분이라는 걸 제대로 파악할 수 있다면, 그게 바로 일의 핵심이에요. 아까 나눈 대화와도 연결되는 부분이죠. 기술과 운영 회사를 처음 만들 때는 기술의 레버리지(leverage)가 어디에 있는지 고민하게 되잖아요. 같은 질문이에요. 기술이 독특하게 해결할 수 있는 진짜 중요한 핵심이 어디에 있는지요.
text_zh: 如果你能真正弄清楚这才是最重要的，那就是这份工作的核心部分。这与我们之前的谈话是相辅相成的。在建立科技和运营公司初期，技术的杠杆在哪里？同样的问题，技术能够独特解决的真正关键是什么？
text_es: Si realmente puedes determinar qué es lo que realmente importa, esa es la parte central del trabajo. Esto se relaciona incluso con nuestra conversación anterior. En los primeros días de construir empresas de tecnología y operaciones, ¿dónde está la palanca tecnológica? La misma pregunta: ¿dónde está el núcleo de lo que realmente importa que la tecnología puede resolver de manera única?
context: Lenny prompts Brian to elaborate on finding the essential elements in product development. Brian emphasizes that identifying what truly matters is critical for product managers, as it guides decision-making. He connects this idea to the importance of understanding where technology can provide leverage in business and product development.
vocabulary_highlights: tech leverage, kernel of what really matters, uniquely solve

speaker: Brian Tolkin
text: You have to be really good at pricing. You have to be really good at product, you have to be really good at the operations. You have to be really disciplined at risk. You have to be really good in the capital markets. And so you have to put all of these functions together to build a vertically integrated product.
text_ko: 가격 책정에 정말 능숙해야 해요. 제품에 대해서도 잘 알아야 하고, 운영도 잘 해야 해요. 리스크 관리에 대해서도 정말 철저해야 하고요. 자본 시장에 대해서도 잘 알아야 해요. 그래서 이 모든 기능을 잘 조합해서 수직 통합된 제품을 만들어야 해요.
text_zh: 你必须在定价方面非常出色，产品方面也要非常优秀，运营管理同样要做到极致。同时，你还需要在风险控制上保持高度的纪律性，并且在资本市场上具备扎实的能力。因此，你需要将所有这些职能整合在一起，构建一个垂直整合的产品。
text_es: Debes ser realmente bueno en la fijación de precios. Debes ser excelente en el producto, en las operaciones y tener una gran disciplina en la gestión del riesgo. También necesitas ser competente en los mercados de capitales. Por lo tanto, es fundamental integrar todas estas funciones para construir un producto verticalmente integrado.
context: Lenny asks Brian about the challenges Zillow faced when entering the real estate market. Brian outlines the multifaceted nature of the business, explaining that success requires excellence across various domains, including pricing, product, operations, and risk management. He stresses the necessity of integrating these functions to create a successful product.
vocabulary_highlights: vertically integrated product, disciplined at risk, capital markets

speaker: Brian Tolkin
text: The reality is vast, vast in our space. A vast majority of people still move the traditional way. And so this isn't something where it's like the size of the prize isn't particularly large enough short or anything like that.
text_ko: 현실은 정말 넓고, 우리 주변도 마찬가지예요. 대부분의 사람들은 여전히 전통적인 방식으로 움직이고 있어요. 그래서 이건 상금의 크기가 특별히 크지 않다는 그런 문제가 아니에요.
text_zh: 现实是广阔的，在我们的领域中更是如此。绝大多数人仍然以传统方式运作。因此，这并不是一个奖赏规模特别大的领域。
text_es: La realidad es amplia, muy amplia en nuestro sector. Una gran mayoría de las personas todavía se mueve de la manera tradicional. Por lo tanto, esto no es algo donde el tamaño de la recompensa (prize) sea particularmente grande en el corto plazo ni nada por el estilo.
context: Lenny queries Brian about the competitive landscape following Zillow's entry into the market. Brian responds by emphasizing that the majority of real estate transactions still occur through traditional methods, indicating that there is ample opportunity for growth in the market. He reassures that staying focused on customer needs is more crucial than being overly concerned about competition.
vocabulary_highlights: size of the prize, vast majority, traditional way

speaker: Cameron Adams
speaker_expertise: Product Management, Product Strategy, Team Building
text: One of those sections is on giving away your Lego, finding joy in the other things of building a team, passing on your experience, helping other people do great writing or great product building or great engineering.
text_ko: 그 섹션 중 하나는 레고를 나누는 것에 대한 거예요. 팀을 만드는 다른 즐거움을 찾고, 자신의 경험을 나누고, 다른 사람들이 훌륭한 글쓰기나 제품 개발, 엔지니어링을 할 수 있도록 도와주는 거죠.
text_zh: 其中一个部分是关于分享你的乐趣，发掘团队建设中的其他乐趣，传承你的经验，帮助他人进行优秀的写作、卓越的产品开发或出色的工程。
text_es: Una de esas secciones trata sobre compartir tus conocimientos, encontrar satisfacción en otros aspectos de construir un equipo, transmitir tu experiencia y ayudar a otras personas a lograr una excelente escritura, desarrollo de productos o ingeniería.
context: Lenny asks Cameron about the culture at Canva. Cameron describes a specific cultural principle called 'giving away your Lego', which emphasizes the importance of sharing knowledge and responsibilities within the team. This concept encourages employees to find fulfillment in mentoring others and contributing to collective success rather than clinging to individual tasks.
vocabulary_highlights: giving away your Lego, building a team, passing on your experience

speaker: Cameron Adams
speaker_expertise: Product Management, Product Strategy, Team Building
text: We don't really have managers, but everyone at Canva has a coach. They're constantly working with you to look at your skills, but also when it might be time to move on to the next level.
text_ko: 우리는 사실 매니저가 없고, 대신 모든 사람이 코치를 가지고 있어요. 코치들은 여러분의 스킬을 살펴보면서, 다음 단계로 나아갈 때가 언제인지도 함께 고민해줘요.
text_zh: 我们在Canva并没有传统意义上的经理，但每个人都有一个教练。他们会不断与你合作，关注你的技能发展，同时也帮助你判断何时该迈向下一个阶段。
text_es: En Canva no tenemos gerentes, pero todos cuentan con un coach. Ellos están constantemente trabajando contigo para evaluar tus habilidades y también para determinar cuándo es el momento de avanzar al siguiente nivel.
context: Lenny inquires about the coaching structure at Canva. Cameron explains that instead of traditional managers, Canva employs a coaching model where each employee has a coach to help them assess their skills and identify opportunities for advancement. This approach fosters personal and professional growth, ensuring that employees have support as they navigate their careers.
vocabulary_highlights: coaching model, move on to the next level

speaker: Cameron Adams
speaker_expertise: Product Management, Product Strategy, Team Building
text: I think there's probably a few different stories that would resonate with your audience because there's like business kind of stories of how the actual company's tracking. There's product stories of stuff we launched that didn't go anywhere.
text_ko: 아마 여러분의 청중과 공감할 수 있는 여러 가지 이야기가 있을 것 같아요. 실제 회사의 진행 상황에 대한 비즈니스 이야기들도 있고, 우리가 출시했지만 별로 반응이 없었던 제품 이야기들도 있거든요.
text_zh: 我认为有几种不同的故事可以引起你们受众的共鸣，因为有关于公司运营的商业故事，还有关于我们推出但没有取得成功的产品故事。
text_es: Creo que probablemente hay varias historias diferentes que resonarían con tu audiencia, ya que hay historias relacionadas con el negocio sobre cómo está avanzando la empresa. También hay historias de productos sobre lanzamientos que no tuvieron éxito.
context: Lenny asks Cameron about moments of struggle within Canva's success narrative. Cameron highlights the importance of sharing both business and product stories, acknowledging that while the company has seen significant achievements, there have also been instances of failure and lessons learned. This nuanced view demonstrates that success is often accompanied by challenges.
vocabulary_highlights: resonate with, product stories

speaker: Cameron Adams
speaker_expertise: Product Management, Product Strategy, Team Building
text: Part of being in a startup is scaling, when you're scaling from zero users to a million to a hundred million, and when you're scaling from three founders to 10 employees to 100 employees to 4,000 employees.
text_ko: 스타트업에서 일하는 건 사용자 수를 제로에서 백만, 백만에서 천만으로 늘리는 과정이기도 해요. 그리고 창립자가 세 명에서 열 명, 열 명에서 백 명, 백 명에서 사천 명으로 늘어나는 것도 마찬가지고요.
text_zh: 创业的一部分就是扩展，从零用户到一百万，再到一亿；从三位创始人到十名员工，再到一百名员工，最后到四千名员工。
text_es: Parte de estar en una startup es escalar; cuando pasas de cero usuarios a un millón, luego a cien millones, y cuando escalas de tres fundadores a 10 empleados, luego a 100 empleados y finalmente a 4,000 empleados.
context: Lenny asks Cameron about the cultural concept of 'giving away your Lego'. Cameron explains that as startups grow, the need for flexibility and collaboration increases. He emphasizes that scaling involves not only expanding user numbers but also adapting internal processes and team dynamics to support this growth.
vocabulary_highlights: scaling, internal processes

speaker: Cameron Adams
speaker_expertise: Product Management, Product Strategy, Team Building
text: We've always been an incredibly product-led company. We always think first and foremost about the product.
text_ko: 우리는 항상 제품 중심의 회사였어요. 항상 제품에 대해 가장 먼저 생각해요.
text_zh: 我们一直是一家以产品为导向的公司。我们始终将产品放在首位。
text_es: Siempre hemos sido una empresa increíblemente enfocada en el producto. Siempre pensamos, ante todo, en el producto.
context: Lenny discusses the focus of Canva's board meetings, which prioritize product updates over financials. Cameron asserts that Canva's identity as a product-led company drives their decision-making process and strategic planning. This commitment to product excellence is integral to their success and aligns with their mission to create valuable experiences for users.
vocabulary_highlights: product-led company, first and foremost

speaker: Cameron Adams
speaker_expertise: Product Management, Product Strategy, Team Building
text: Freemium for us wasn't so much a growth strategy or a monetization strategy as much as it spoke to our core mission of empowering the world to design.
text_ko: 프리미엄 모델(freemium)은 우리에게 성장 전략이나 수익화 전략이라기보다는, 세상을 디자인할 수 있도록 돕는 우리의 핵심 미션을 잘 보여주는 거였어요.
text_zh: 对我们来说，Freemium 并不是一种增长策略或盈利策略，而是体现了我们赋能全球设计的核心使命。
text_es: Para nosotros, el modelo freemium no fue tanto una estrategia de crecimiento o de monetización, sino que reflejó nuestra misión fundamental de empoderar al mundo para diseñar.
context: Lenny asks about Canva's freemium strategy. Cameron clarifies that their freemium model aligns with their mission to democratize design rather than solely serving as a growth tactic. By making their tools accessible to a broader audience, Canva enhances its brand value and encourages widespread use of its platform.
vocabulary_highlights: freemium model, democratize design

speaker: Cameron Adams
speaker_expertise: Product Management, Product Strategy, Team Building
text: We don't need to create an LLM because it's a commodity thing now. And there's a bunch of providers who can do it way better and have way more resources to do it with than you do.
text_ko: 이제 LLM을 만들 필요 없어요. 그건 이미 일반화된 거라서, 훨씬 더 잘하고 자원도 많은 공급자들이 많거든요.
text_zh: 我们不需要再开发大型语言模型（LLM），因为这已经成为一种商品化的产品。现在有很多供应商能够做得更好，并且拥有比我们更多的资源。
text_es: No necesitamos crear un LLM (modelo de lenguaje grande) porque ahora es algo común. Hay muchos proveedores que pueden hacerlo mucho mejor y cuentan con muchos más recursos para lograrlo que nosotros.
context: Lenny raises the topic of AI integration at Canva. Cameron explains that rather than developing their own large language models (LLMs), they focus on leveraging partnerships with established AI providers. This strategic decision allows Canva to utilize advanced technology without the significant resource investment, emphasizing the importance of collaboration in tech development.
vocabulary_highlights: commodity, providers

speaker: Camille Fournier
text: A lot of people assume that engineers just write code and don't underestimate the ability for your engineers to want to understand the business problem, want to understand the customer problem.
text_ko: 많은 사람들이 엔지니어가 단순히 코드를 작성한다고 생각하는데, 엔지니어들이 비즈니스 문제나 고객 문제를 이해하고 싶어하는 능력을 과소평가하지 마세요.
text_zh: 很多人认为工程师只是写代码，但不要低估工程师理解业务问题和客户需求的能力。
text_es: Muchas personas asumen que los ingenieros solo escriben código, pero no subestimes la capacidad de tus ingenieros para querer entender el problema del negocio y el problema del cliente.
context: Lenny asks Camille about the motivations of engineers and what excites them. Camille emphasizes that engineers are often underestimated in their desire to grasp the broader business and customer issues, highlighting the importance of product managers acknowledging this interest to foster better collaboration.
vocabulary_highlights: underestimate, business problem, customer problem

speaker: Camille Fournier
text: Making every effort to be credit sharing and inclusive of the engineering team and giving them the opportunity to speak about their contributions when it makes sense.
text_ko: 엔지니어링 팀이 기여한 부분에 대해 이야기할 수 있는 기회를 주고, 그들의 노력을 인정하고 포용하는 데 최선을 다하는 게 중요해요.
text_zh: 尽全力与工程团队共享荣誉，确保他们在合适的时机有机会谈论自己的贡献。
text_es: Haciendo todo lo posible por compartir el crédito e incluir al equipo de ingeniería, dándoles la oportunidad de hablar sobre sus contribuciones cuando sea pertinente.
context: Lenny inquires about behaviors that PMs can change to avoid annoying engineers. Camille suggests that PMs should consciously share credit for projects and provide engineers with opportunities to discuss their contributions, which fosters a more inclusive environment and reduces frustration among team members.
vocabulary_highlights: credit sharing, inclusive, contributions

speaker: Camille Fournier
text: If you are being asked questions that you cannot answer because you just don't know or because that's something that involves a level of technical detail that only the engineers have... that drives engineers, particularly senior engineers on projects, it's crazy.
text_ko: 모르는 질문을 받거나 기술적인 세부사항이 필요한 질문을 받으면, 특히 프로젝트의 시니어 엔지니어들은 정말 힘들어해요. 그게 정말 미치겠죠.
text_zh: 如果你被问到一些你无法回答的问题，因为你不知道答案，或者这些问题涉及的技术细节只有工程师才能掌握……这会让工程师，尤其是项目中的高级工程师，感到非常困扰。
text_es: Si te hacen preguntas que no puedes responder porque simplemente no lo sabes o porque se trata de un nivel de detalle técnico que solo los ingenieros manejan... eso frustra a los ingenieros, especialmente a los ingenieros senior en los proyectos, es una locura.
context: Lenny asks Camille about behaviors that PMs exhibit that frustrate engineers. Camille explains that when PMs play the middleman and cannot answer technical questions, it creates inefficiencies and annoys engineers, particularly those in senior roles who expect direct communication.
vocabulary_highlights: technical detail, senior engineers, middleman

speaker: Camille Fournier
text: Most of the time, you can't really afford to just say we're going to go away and we're not going to touch the system for a long time and we're going to build something new over here.
text_ko: 대부분의 경우, 그냥 시스템을 손대지 않고 오랫동안 떠나서 새로운 걸 만들겠다고 할 수는 없어요.
text_zh: 大多数情况下，你不能仅仅说我们要离开一段时间，不去触碰系统，而是在这里重新构建一些新东西。
text_es: La mayoría de las veces, no puedes permitirte simplemente decir que nos vamos a alejar y que no vamos a tocar el sistema durante un largo tiempo, y que vamos a construir algo nuevo por aquí.
context: Lenny prompts Camille to elaborate on her view that rewrites can be traps. Camille warns that taking a long break from the current system to build something new often leads to complications, as teams typically underestimate the time needed for migration and the necessity of maintaining existing systems.
vocabulary_highlights: afford, touch the system, build something new

speaker: Camille Fournier
text: If you don't have any software engineers on your platform team and you only have more operations systems engineers, DevOps, SRE... you're kind of missing the picture.
text_ko: 플랫폼 팀에 소프트웨어 엔지니어가 없고 운영 시스템 엔지니어, DevOps, SRE만 있다면, 뭔가 중요한 걸 놓치고 있는 거예요.
text_zh: 如果你的平台团队没有软件工程师，只有运维系统工程师、DevOps、SRE等角色，那你可能会错失关键的视角。
text_es: Si no tienes ingenieros de software en tu equipo de plataforma y solo cuentas con ingenieros de sistemas de operaciones, DevOps, SRE, etc., te estás perdiendo de la perspectiva completa.
context: Lenny inquires about structuring effective platform teams. Camille stresses the importance of including software engineers alongside operations and DevOps personnel, as platform engineering requires a mix of skills to create cohesive and effective products that support engineering productivity.
vocabulary_highlights: operations systems engineers, DevOps, cohesive

speaker: Camille Fournier
text: I think when you see people that are 23, they are just out, very recently out of school, it's a different thing if you're a founder... but if you're at a big company and somebody is like you have great communication skills, why don't you start to become a manager?
text_ko: 23살인 사람들을 보면, 막 학교를 졸업한 경우가 많잖아요. 창업자라면 다르겠지만, 큰 회사에 다니면서 누군가가 "너는 커뮤니케이션 능력이 뛰어난데, 왜 매니저가 되지 않니?"라고 하면 좀 다른 느낌이죠.
text_zh: 我认为，当你看到23岁的人，他们刚刚从学校毕业，如果你是创始人，那是另一回事……但如果你在大公司工作，有人对你说你沟通能力很强，为什么不考虑成为一名经理呢？
text_es: Creo que cuando ves a personas de 23 años, que recién han salido de la escuela, es diferente si eres un fundador... pero si estás en una gran empresa y alguien te dice que tienes excelentes habilidades de comunicación, ¿por qué no comienzas a convertirte en un gerente?
context: Lenny asks Camille about the common timeline for engineers transitioning into management roles. Camille comments on the issue of young professionals being pushed into management too early in their careers, suggesting that they should spend more time developing technical skills before taking on such responsibilities.
vocabulary_highlights: transitioning, pushed, responsibilities

speaker: Camille Hearst
text: One of the things that we also know is it's not just the big huge superstars who have those rabid and super engaged fan bases. People are really passionate just about supporting the artists that they love in general.
text_ko: 우리가 아는 것 중 하나는, 정말 유명한 슈퍼스타들만 열정적인 팬층을 가지고 있는 게 아니라는 거예요. 사람들은 자신이 좋아하는 아티스트를 지원하는 데 정말 열정적이에요.
text_zh: 我们知道，不仅仅是那些大牌明星拥有狂热且高度参与的粉丝群体。人们对支持他们喜爱的艺术家普遍充满热情。
text_es: Una de las cosas que también sabemos es que no son solo las grandes superestrellas las que cuentan con bases de fans tan apasionadas y comprometidas. La gente realmente siente una gran pasión por apoyar a los artistas que aman en general.
context: Lenny inquires about Camille's role at Spotify as head of fan monetization. Camille explains that her team focuses on developing new ways to facilitate connections between artists and their fans. She emphasizes that even lesser-known artists have dedicated supporters and that Spotify aims to transform this enthusiasm into monetization opportunities for the artists.
vocabulary_highlights: rabid, engaged fan bases, monetization opportunities

speaker: Camille Hearst
text: To some degree, there has to be a value exchange that happens in order for a creative person to live from their art.
text_ko: 어느 정도는 창작자가 자신의 예술로 살아가기 위해서 가치 교환이 필요해요.
text_zh: 在某种程度上，创意人士必须进行价值交换，才能通过他们的艺术谋生。
text_es: En cierta medida, debe existir un intercambio de valor para que una persona creativa pueda vivir de su arte.
context: Lenny asks Camille about the best and worst parts of working with artists. Camille reflects on the difficulty artists face in wanting to share their work for free due to their passion for their craft. She highlights the necessity of a value exchange, meaning that artists need to receive compensation for their work to sustain their livelihoods.
vocabulary_highlights: value exchange, sustain livelihoods

speaker: Camille Hearst
text: But I do think that this area continues to be untapped. I just don't see a world where... I think of Michelle Phan, right? She's basically a mini Disney and when you think of it like that, she's created IP.
text_ko: 하지만 이 분야는 여전히 개발되지 않은 것 같아요. 저는 그런 세상이 있다고 생각하지 않아요... 미셸 판(Michelle Phan)을 생각해보면, 그녀는 사실상 미니 디즈니(mini Disney 같은 존재잖아요. 그렇게 생각하면, 그녀는 IP(지식재산권)를 만들어낸 거죠.
text_zh: 但我确实认为这个领域仍然有待开发。我无法想象一个世界……我想到米歇尔·潘（Michelle Phan），对吧？她基本上就是一个迷你迪士尼，当你这样想的时候，她实际上创造了知识产权（IP）。
text_es: Pero creo que esta área sigue sin explotar. Simplemente no veo un mundo en el que... Pienso en Michelle Phan, ¿verdad? Ella es básicamente un mini Disney y, al pensarlo así, ha creado propiedad intelectual (IP).
context: Lenny prompts Camille to discuss the future of the creator economy. Camille argues that the potential for creators to thrive is far from exhausted, using the example of Michelle Phan, a successful content creator who has built a personal brand akin to a mini Disney. She emphasizes that creating intellectual property (IP) opens doors for various revenue streams and opportunities for creators.
vocabulary_highlights: untapped, intellectual property, revenue streams

speaker: Camille Hearst
text: I think it was probably predictable to some degree that platforms would win because just of the nature of aggregation.
text_ko: 플랫폼이 이길 거라는 건 어느 정도 예측 가능했을 것 같아요. 결국 집합의 특성 때문이죠.
text_zh: 我认为，平台的胜出在某种程度上是可以预见的，因为这与聚合的本质有关。
text_es: Creo que era predecible hasta cierto punto que las plataformas ganarían debido a la naturaleza de la agregación.
context: Lenny asks Camille about the trajectory of the creator economy and platforms. Camille reflects on the strong network effect that comes from aggregation, meaning that once a platform consolidates enough creators or consumers, it becomes difficult for new entrants to compete. She notes that established platforms are strategically enhancing features to retain creators and prevent them from leaving.
vocabulary_highlights: predictable, nature of aggregation, network effect

speaker: Camille Hearst
text: So one of the things that I've seen that I don't know if people realize is consistency and predictability of content creation.
text_ko: 제가 본 것 중 하나는 사람들이 잘 인식하지 못하는 부분인데, 콘텐츠 제작에서 일관성과 예측 가능성이 정말 중요하다는 거예요.
text_zh: 我观察到的一个方面是，内容创作的一致性和可预测性，很多人可能并没有意识到这一点。
text_es: Una de las cosas que he observado y que no sé si la gente se da cuenta es la importancia de la consistencia y la predictibilidad en la creación de contenido.
context: Lenny asks Camille about important factors for success in the creator economy. Camille points out that consistency and predictability in content creation are crucial for creators to build an audience. She compares this to the concept of putting in '10,000 hours' to master a skill, indicating that regular output helps creators improve and connect with their audience.
vocabulary_highlights: consistency, predictability, master a skill

speaker: Camille Hearst
text: What I learned and that we really emphasized during that time is this idea of having dual track agile going where you're doing discovery and delivery simultaneously.
text_ko: 그때 제가 배운 것 중 하나는 동시에 탐색(discovery)과 전달(delivery)을 진행하는 이중 트랙(dual track) 애자일의 중요성이에요.
text_zh: 我在那段时间学到的，并且我们非常强调的，就是同时进行探索（discovery）和交付（delivery）的双轨敏捷（dual track agile）理念。
text_es: Lo que aprendí y que realmente enfatizamos durante ese tiempo es esta idea de tener un enfoque ágil de doble vía, donde se realiza la exploración (discovery) y la entrega (delivery) de manera simultánea.
context: Lenny asks Camille about her favorite frameworks for building products. Camille discusses the 'dual track agile' methodology, which involves conducting discovery (research and validation of ideas) and delivery (actual product development) at the same time. This approach helps teams de-risk assumptions and innovate effectively while responding to user needs.
vocabulary_highlights: dual track agile, discovery and delivery, de-risk assumptions

speaker: Camille Ricketts
text: The way that you think about product market fit, you have to think about content market fit. So even though content feels like it's running adjacent to the actual product that you're putting out there, you still have to think about who is my audience?
text_ko: 제품 시장 적합성(product market fit)을 생각하는 방식처럼, 콘텐츠 시장 적합성(content market fit)도 생각해야 해요. 콘텐츠가 실제로 내놓는 제품과는 조금 다른 것처럼 느껴질 수 있지만, 여전히 "내가 누구를 대상으로 하고 있지?"를 고민해야 해요.
text_zh: 在考虑产品市场契合度（product market fit）时，也要考虑内容市场契合度（content market fit）。尽管内容似乎与您推出的实际产品并行，但您仍然需要思考我的受众是谁？
text_es: La forma en que piensas sobre el ajuste del producto en el mercado (product market fit) también se aplica al ajuste del contenido en el mercado (content market fit). Aunque el contenido parece estar relacionado con el producto que ofreces, aún debes considerar quién es tu audiencia.
context: Lenny asks Camille about the key considerations in content marketing. Camille explains that just as product market fit is essential for a product’s success, content market fit is crucial for content strategies. She emphasizes the importance of deeply understanding your audience and their needs to create effective content that resonates with them.
vocabulary_highlights: content market fit, adjacent, resonate

speaker: Camille Ricketts
text: What is it that they really need in their lives? Even abstracting content from it at all. What is it that they need to get promoted? What is it that they need to avoid failure?
text_ko: 그들이 정말로 필요한 게 뭘까? 내용을 추상화하더라도 말이야. 승진하려면 뭘 해야 할까? 실패를 피하려면 뭘 해야 할까?
text_zh: 他们在生活中真正需要的是什么？即使抽象化内容也无妨。他们需要什么才能获得晋升？他们需要什么才能避免失败？
text_es: ¿Qué es lo que realmente necesitan en sus vidas? Incluso dejando de lado el contenido. ¿Qué es lo que necesitan para ser promovidos? ¿Qué es lo que deben evitar para no fracasar?
context: Lenny inquires about how to determine what content will be valuable to an audience. Camille highlights the necessity of identifying the specific needs of the audience, such as their aspirations for promotion or their concerns about failure. This understanding is essential for crafting content that addresses their real-life challenges.
vocabulary_highlights: abstracting, avoid failure

speaker: Camille Ricketts
text: One of the worst things you can do is say, let's cut this off at the knees if it's not generating ROI.
text_ko: ROI가 안 나온다고 해서 무조건 잘라버리자고 하는 건 정말 안 좋은 선택이에요.
text_zh: 最糟糕的做法之一就是在没有产生投资回报（ROI）的情况下，立即决定终止项目。
text_es: Una de las peores cosas que puedes hacer es decir, cortemos esto de raíz si no está generando ROI.
context: Lenny asks Camille about the metrics for assessing community-led growth initiatives. Camille advises against prematurely cutting community efforts due to a lack of immediate return on investment (ROI). She argues that community initiatives often yield long-term benefits that may not be immediately measurable.
vocabulary_highlights: cut this off at the knees, generating ROI

speaker: Camille Ricketts
text: True discovery is when you have intent to find out more. You've heard about it so many times or you've been intrigued by something that someone has told you to the extent that you're actually going to take the step of now learning about it.
text_ko: 진정한 발견은 더 알고 싶다는 의도가 있을 때 이루어져요. 누군가가 이야기한 것에 매료되거나 여러 번 들어서 이제는 실제로 그에 대해 배우려고 하는 단계에 이르는 거죠.
text_zh: 真正的发现是当你有意愿去深入了解。你听说过很多次，或者被某人告诉的某件事所吸引，以至于你决定迈出学习的第一步。
text_es: El verdadero descubrimiento ocurre cuando tienes la intención de profundizar más. Has escuchado sobre ello tantas veces o te ha intrigado algo que alguien te ha dicho, hasta el punto de que realmente vas a dar el paso de aprender al respecto.
context: Lenny discusses the concept of community-led growth and asks Camille to elaborate on its significance. Camille defines discovery in the context of community engagement as the point when potential customers, having been repeatedly exposed to a product, actively seek to learn more about it. This level of engagement is crucial for driving deeper connections with the audience.
vocabulary_highlights: intent, intrigued, learning about it

speaker: Camille Ricketts
text: I think that community lends itself particularly well if you have something that your product creates that people want to share because it exhibits something about themselves.
text_ko: 저는 제품이 사람들한테 자신을 드러낼 수 있는 무언가를 만들어서 공유하고 싶어하는 경우, 커뮤니티가 특히 잘 어울린다고 생각해요.
text_zh: 我认为，如果你的产品能够创造出人们愿意分享的东西，因为它展示了他们的某种特质，那么社区的建设会特别有效。
text_es: Creo que la comunidad se presta especialmente bien si tu producto genera algo que las personas quieren compartir porque refleja algo sobre sí mismas.
context: Lenny asks Camille about when it makes sense to invest in community efforts. Camille explains that community is most effective for products that encourage users to share their creations, as this showcases their personal identity. Products that have a strong sharing component can benefit significantly from community-led growth strategies.
vocabulary_highlights: lends itself, exhibits

speaker: Camille Ricketts
text: Making sure that they have a place to gather and a place to feel like they are more connected with your team than the average person gets to be.
text_ko: 팀원들이 평균적인 사람들보다 더 연결되어 있다고 느낄 수 있는 공간을 마련해주는 게 중요해요.
text_zh: 确保他们有一个聚集的地方，以及一个能让他们感受到与您的团队比普通人更紧密联系的环境。
text_es: Asegurarse de que tengan un lugar para reunirse y un espacio donde se sientan más conectados con su equipo que la persona promedio.
context: Lenny asks Camille about the role of ‘champions’ in community building. Camille emphasizes the importance of creating exclusive spaces for enthusiastic users that allow them to feel a deeper connection with the company. This approach fosters loyalty and engagement among key users who can amplify the brand.
vocabulary_highlights: gather, connected

speaker: Carilu Dietrich
text: In order to get hypergrowth, you have to have organic, inbound, and viral word of mouth. You can't pay enough to grow at those rates and have a viable company.
text_ko: 하이퍼그로스(hypergrowth)를 이루려면 유기적인(organic), 인바운드(inbound), 그리고 바이럴(viral) 입소문이 필요해요. 그런 속도로 성장하려면 돈으로 해결할 수 없고, 지속 가능한 회사가 될 수 없어요.
text_zh: 要实现超高速增长，必须依靠有机增长、内生增长和病毒式口碑传播。单靠支付费用无法达到这样的增长率，也无法维持一个可持续的公司。
text_es: Para lograr un hipercrecimiento, es necesario contar con un boca a boca orgánico, entrante y viral. No puedes pagar lo suficiente para crecer a esos ritmos y tener una empresa viable.
context: Lenny asks Carilu about the key components that contribute to hypergrowth in companies. Carilu explains that achieving hypergrowth relies on organic growth methods such as word of mouth, rather than relying on paid marketing strategies. She emphasizes that a product that users love is essential for sustaining such growth.
vocabulary_highlights: hypergrowth, organic growth, viral word of mouth

speaker: Carilu Dietrich
text: Hypergrowth companies go through the stages of growth that would take other companies five years or 10 years, right? They're going from 10 to 50, they're going from 50 to 100, they're going from 100 to 200.
text_ko: 하이퍼그로스(hypergrowth) 기업들은 다른 기업들이 5년이나 10년 걸릴 성장 단계를 짧은 시간 안에 지나가요. 10에서 50으로, 50에서 100으로, 그리고 100에서 200으로 성장하는 거죠.
text_zh: 超高速增长的公司经历的成长阶段，其他公司可能需要五年或十年才能完成，对吧？它们从10增长到50，从50增长到100，从100增长到200。
text_es: Las empresas en hipercrecimiento atraviesan etapas de crecimiento que a otras empresas les llevarían cinco o diez años, ¿verdad? Están pasando de 10 a 50, de 50 a 100, de 100 a 200.
context: Lenny and Carilu discuss the characteristics of hypergrowth companies. Carilu describes how these companies experience rapid growth in a compressed time frame, achieving milestones that would typically take much longer for traditional companies. This rapid scaling requires hiring leaders who are experienced in navigating the next stages of growth.
vocabulary_highlights: hypergrowth, stages of growth, compressed time frame

speaker: Carilu Dietrich
text: If you're unemployed, it's tough. It's a tough time. There's a lot of supply. And so I think you just really need endurance and grit.
text_ko: 실직 상태면 힘든 시기예요. 공급이 많아서 더 어려운 것 같아요. 그래서 정말 인내심과 끈기가 필요하다고 생각해요.
text_zh: 如果你失业了，这段时间确实很困难。市场上竞争激烈，供给过剩。因此，我认为你需要具备耐力和韧性。
text_es: Si estás desempleado, es difícil. Es un momento complicado. Hay mucha oferta. Por eso creo que realmente necesitas resistencia y determinación.
context: Lenny asks Carilu for advice for individuals trying to find a job in a challenging market. Carilu acknowledges the difficulties of being unemployed and stresses the importance of resilience and perseverance, or 'grit,' during tough economic times. She emphasizes that maintaining endurance is crucial for eventual success.
vocabulary_highlights: endurance, grit, challenging market

speaker: Carilu Dietrich
text: Picking your industry will propel your career, and picking the right company will propel your career, and then doing a good job will propel your career.
text_ko: 산업을 잘 선택하면 경력이 쭉 뻗어나가고, 그 다음에 좋은 회사를 선택하면 더 잘 나가고, 마지막으로 일을 잘 하면 경력이 더 발전해요.
text_zh: 选择行业能推动你的职业发展，选择合适的公司也能推动你的职业发展，而做好本职工作更能推动你的职业发展。
text_es: Elegir tu industria impulsará tu carrera, seleccionar la empresa adecuada también la impulsará, y hacer un buen trabajo la llevará aún más lejos.
context: Lenny and Carilu discuss strategies for accelerating career growth. Carilu explains that choosing the right industry and company can significantly influence one’s career trajectory. She emphasizes that consistent performance and quality work are equally important for advancing one's professional journey.
vocabulary_highlights: propel, career trajectory, consistent performance

speaker: Carilu Dietrich
text: There's no shortcuts to knowing a lot. One of the people I admire most is Tomasz Tunguz... he was like, 'I'd just wake up 5:00 or 6:00 AM every morning and write three to four blogs a week for 10 years.'
text_ko: 많은 것을 아는 데는 지름길이 없어요. 제가 가장 존경하는 사람 중 한 명인 Tomasz Tunguz가 이렇게 말했어요. '나는 매일 아침 5시나 6시에 일어나서 10년 동안 매주 블로그를 3개에서 4개씩 썼어.'
text_zh: 没有捷径可以获得丰富的知识。我最钦佩的人之一是Tomasz Tunguz，他曾说过：“我每天早上5点或6点起床，每周写三到四篇博客，持续了十年。”
text_es: No hay atajos para adquirir conocimiento. Una de las personas que más admiro es Tomasz Tunguz... él decía: 'Me despertaba a las 5:00 o 6:00 AM cada mañana y escribía de tres a cuatro blogs a la semana durante 10 años.'
context: Lenny asks Carilu about the value of hard work in achieving success. Carilu shares her admiration for Tomasz Tunguz, who dedicated significant time and effort to writing consistently over many years. She underscores that there are no shortcuts to acquiring knowledge, and that discipline is essential for success.
vocabulary_highlights: shortcuts, admiration, discipline

speaker: Carilu Dietrich
text: The CMO isn't focused enough on the revenue. So some CMOs get focused more on the pipeline or the awareness, and the CEO doesn't feel like they really have a partner in driving the revenue.
text_ko: CMO가 수익에 충분히 집중하지 않는 경우가 있어요. 그래서 어떤 CMO들은 파이프라인(pipeline)이나 인지도(awareness)에 더 신경 쓰고, 그러다 보니 CEO는 수익을 올리는 데 진정한 파트너가 없다고 느끼는 것 같아요.
text_zh: 首席营销官（CMO）对收入的关注不够。有些首席营销官更关注销售渠道（pipeline）或品牌认知（awareness），而首席执行官（CEO）则感觉他们在推动收入方面并没有真正的合作伙伴。
text_es: El CMO no está lo suficientemente enfocado en los ingresos. Algunos CMOs se centran más en el pipeline o en la visibilidad, y el CEO siente que no tiene un verdadero socio en la generación de ingresos.
context: Carilu discusses the challenges faced by Chief Marketing Officers (CMOs) in building trust with CEOs. She points out that many CMOs fail to prioritize revenue generation, which can lead to a lack of partnership with the CEO. This disconnect often results in CMOs being perceived as less effective.
vocabulary_highlights: pipeline, revenue generation, disconnect

speaker: Chris Hutchins
text: So the easiest way to be in that top 5% ish. I don't know what the math there is. About 3%, 4% is to just stick to it. Like if you just do an episode a week for 10 weeks, you're now in the top 4% of all podcasts that anyone has created.
text_ko: 상위 5%에 들어가는 가장 쉬운 방법은 꾸준히 하는 거예요. 정확한 수치는 잘 모르겠지만, 대충 3%나 4% 정도 될 거예요. 예를 들어, 10주 동안 매주 한 편씩 에피소드를 올리면, 그럼 모든 팟캐스트 중에서 상위 4%에 들어가게 되는 거죠.
text_zh: 要进入前5%的最简单方法就是坚持下去。我不太清楚具体的数学计算，大约是3%到4%。如果你每周发布一集节目，持续10周，你就能进入所有播客中的前4%。
text_es: La forma más sencilla de estar en ese 5% superior es, simplemente, mantener la constancia. Si publicas un episodio a la semana durante 10 semanas, ya estarás en el 4% superior de todos los podcasts que se han creado.
context: Lenny discusses the vast number of podcasts available and asks Chris about the potential for success in podcasting. Chris explains that a significant portion of podcasts remain inactive, and by consistently releasing episodes, a new podcast can quickly rise to the top percentage of all podcasts, showcasing the power of persistence in content creation.
vocabulary_highlights: top 5% ish, stick to it, top 4% of all podcasts

speaker: Chris Hutchins
text: If you just do an episode a week, for 10 weeks, you're now in the top 4% of all podcasts that anyone has created.
text_ko: 주 1회씩 10주 동안 에피소드를 올리기만 해도, 모든 팟캐스트 중에서 상위 4%에 들어가게 돼요.
text_zh: 如果你每周发布一集，持续10周，你就能进入所有播客的前4%。
text_es: Si solo produces un episodio a la semana durante 10 semanas, estarás en el top 4% de todos los podcasts que se han creado.
context: In response to Lenny's inquiry about the podcast landscape, Chris highlights the importance of consistency in podcasting. He emphasizes that simply maintaining a weekly episode schedule for a short period can place a podcast in the top percentile of existing shows, underscoring the relatively low barrier to entry for achieving visibility.
vocabulary_highlights: top 4% of all podcasts, anyone has created

speaker: Chris Hutchins
text: But figuring out how to create excitement internally and get buy-in from other teams because they're the ones that are going to build it. They're the ones that are going to help market.
text_ko: 내부에서 흥미를 유도하고 다른 팀들의 동의를 얻는 방법을 찾는 게 중요해요. 그 팀들이 실제로 만들고, 마케팅도 도와줄 사람들이니까요.
text_zh: 但关键在于如何在内部激发热情，并获得其他团队的支持，因为他们将是实施这一方案的人，他们也将帮助进行市场推广。
text_es: Pero hay que encontrar la manera de generar entusiasmo internamente y conseguir el apoyo de otros equipos, ya que son ellos quienes lo van a construir. Son ellos quienes ayudarán a comercializarlo.
context: Lenny prompts Chris to share insights on successful innovation within larger companies. Chris explains that while understanding customer needs is vital, generating enthusiasm and securing support from various teams is equally important. This internal buy-in is crucial, as these teams will execute, market, and ultimately determine the success of a product.
vocabulary_highlights: create excitement internally, get buy-in

speaker: Chris Hutchins
text: The harsh reality of this whole game is like there's probably going to be a number of months or years you have to do it for free before it takes off. So if you don't love it, that's going to be a painful few years.
text_ko: 이 게임의 현실은 아마도 몇 개월 또는 몇 년 동안은 무료로 해야 할 수도 있다는 거예요. 그래서 만약 이 일을 사랑하지 않으면, 힘든 몇 년이 될 거예요.
text_zh: 这个行业的残酷现实是，你可能需要无偿付出几个月甚至几年，才能看到成果。因此，如果你不热爱这份工作，这将是几年的痛苦经历。
text_es: La dura realidad de este negocio es que probablemente habrá varios meses o incluso años en los que tendrás que trabajar sin remuneración antes de que despegue. Así que, si no lo amas, esos años pueden ser muy difíciles.
context: In discussing the challenges of starting a podcast, Chris emphasizes the potential long-term commitment and effort required before achieving success. He stresses the importance of passion for the topic, as those who do not genuinely enjoy the process may find it challenging over time. This insight serves as a reminder to choose subjects that ignite enthusiasm.
vocabulary_highlights: harsh reality, painful few years

speaker: Chris Hutchins
text: So I just think it's a simple way to build a podcasting website. The only other thing, we didn't talk at all about analytics at all, but I use Chartable for analytics.
text_ko: 그래서 저는 팟캐스트 웹사이트를 만드는 게 정말 간단하다고 생각해요. 그리고 하나 더, 우리는 분석에 대해서는 전혀 얘기하지 않았는데, 저는 분석을 위해 Chartable을 사용해요.
text_zh: 我认为建立一个播客网站的方法很简单。我们没有讨论分析（analytics），但我使用Chartable进行数据分析。
text_es: Así que creo que es una forma sencilla de crear un sitio web de podcasting. Lo único que no mencionamos en absoluto son las analíticas, pero yo utilizo Chartable para eso.
context: Lenny and Chris are discussing the podcasting tools and software they use. Chris shares his experience with using Podpage for creating a podcast website and mentions Chartable for analytics. He highlights the importance of having a user-friendly website and effective analytics to track podcast performance.
vocabulary_highlights: build a podcasting website, analytics

speaker: Chris Hutchins
text: One thing that I always say is, if you're going to dinner party, you now know someone's address. You probably know their name instead of bringing a bottle of wine or in addition, just check if they have unclaimed money.
text_ko: 제가 항상 하는 말이 있어요. 만약 저녁 파티에 간다면, 그 사람의 주소는 알게 되잖아요. 그 사람의 이름도 알겠죠. 그러니까 와인 한 병을 가져가는 대신에, 혹은 추가로, 그 사람이 받을 수 있는 돈이 있는지 확인해보는 것도 좋을 것 같아요.
text_zh: 我常说的一句话是，如果你要去参加晚宴，你现在知道了某人的地址。你可能知道他们的名字，不妨在带一瓶酒之前，先查一下他们是否有未领取的款项。
text_es: Una cosa que siempre digo es que, si vas a una cena, ahora conoces la dirección de alguien. Probablemente sepas su nombre, así que en lugar de llevar una botella de vino o además de eso, solo verifica si tienen dinero no reclamado.
context: Chris shares a creative money hack about checking for unclaimed funds that a person might be owed. He suggests that knowing someone's name and address can lead to a fun conversation at social gatherings by revealing whether they have unclaimed money. This approach not only serves as a clever icebreaker but can also benefit the individual receiving the information.
vocabulary_highlights: unclaimed money, icebreaker

speaker: Christian Idiodi
text: The core of product management is competency-based, meaning there is someone in an organization that represents the customer the best, that has a deep knowledge of the customers and your users, that has a deep knowledge of your data, your industry, your business and the product itself.
text_ko: 제품 관리의 핵심은 역량 기반이에요. 즉, 고객을 가장 잘 대변하는 사람이 조직 내에 있어야 하고, 고객과 사용자에 대한 깊은 이해가 필요해요. 그리고 데이터, 산업, 비즈니스, 제품 자체에 대해서도 잘 알아야 해요.
text_zh: 产品管理的核心是基于能力的，这意味着在一个组织中，有人能够最好地代表客户，具备对客户和用户的深刻理解，同时对数据、行业、业务和产品本身也有深入的了解。
text_es: El núcleo de la gestión de productos se basa en competencias, lo que significa que hay alguien en la organización que representa mejor al cliente, que tiene un profundo conocimiento de los clientes y los usuarios, así como un amplio entendimiento de tus datos, tu industria, tu negocio y el producto en sí.
context: Lenny discusses the common dislike for product managers and asks Christian why this is often the case. Christian explains that many people dislike product managers because they have not experienced effective ones. He highlights that the role of a product manager should be competency-based, where they possess deep knowledge about customers, data, and the product, allowing them to make informed decisions that benefit the organization.
vocabulary_highlights: competency-based, represent the customer, deep knowledge, mistrust

speaker: Christian Idiodi
text: I often say to him, I say, 'Well, Bob said put up manager.' And it's often interesting to executives when I try to explain that way. I say that's the competent level that we're talking about here.
text_ko: 저는 그에게 자주 이렇게 말해요, '음, 밥이 매니저를 세우라고 했어.' 이렇게 설명하면 경영진들이 흥미롭게 생각하는 경우가 많아요. 제가 말하는 건 우리가 이야기하는 유능한 수준이라는 거예요.
text_zh: 我常对他说：“好吧，鲍勃说要提升经理。”我发现这样解释对高管们来说通常很有趣。我说，这就是我们所谈论的能力水平。
text_es: A menudo le digo, 'Bueno, Bob dijo que se debe poner al gerente.' Y suele ser interesante para los ejecutivos cuando trato de explicarlo de esa manera. Digo que ese es el nivel de competencia (competent level) del que estamos hablando aquí.
context: In response to Lenny's question about the dislike for product managers, Christian illustrates how executives often trust long-serving employees over product managers due to their perceived competence. He uses the example of a hypothetical Bob, who has been with the company for a long time and is trusted to make decisions, to emphasize that product managers must demonstrate their competency to be respected and trusted in their decision-making.
vocabulary_highlights: competent level, displaced influence, mistrust

speaker: Christian Idiodi
text: There is this period of humility that I challenge all product managers to have, this period of learning, recognizing what you do not know.
text_ko: 모든 제품 관리자에게 도전하고 싶은 겸손의 시기가 있어요. 배우고, 내가 모르는 것을 인식하는 그런 시기요.
text_zh: 我鼓励所有产品经理经历一个谦逊的阶段，这是一个学习的过程，认识到自己所不知道的事情。
text_es: Hay un período de humildad que desafío a todos los gerentes de producto a tener, un período de aprendizaje, reconociendo lo que no saben.
context: Lenny asks Christian how product managers can become more effective and less disliked. Christian stresses the importance of humility and a willingness to learn for product managers. He suggests that they should recognize their limitations and actively seek mentorship and knowledge from experienced colleagues to build their competence and trust within the organization.
vocabulary_highlights: period of humility, challenge, recognizing limitations

speaker: Christian Idiodi
text: I always practically advise product managers in this kind of scenario, build relationships with people. You earn their trust by asking them to do two things. One, you're either going to teach me or I'm going to help you.
text_ko: 이런 상황에서는 제품 관리자들에게 항상 이렇게 조언해요. 사람들과 관계를 잘 쌓아야 해요. 신뢰를 얻으려면 두 가지를 요청하면 돼요. 하나는, 당신이 나에게 가르쳐주거나, 아니면 내가 당신을 도와줄게요.
text_zh: 在这种情况下，我总是建议产品经理建立人际关系。通过让他们做两件事来赢得他们的信任。第一，你要么教我，要么我来帮助你。
text_es: Siempre aconsejo a los gerentes de producto en este tipo de situaciones que construyan relaciones con las personas. Ganas su confianza pidiéndoles que hagan dos cosas. Primero, o me vas a enseñar o yo te voy a ayudar.
context: Christian shares practical advice for product managers to build trust and rapport within their teams. He emphasizes the importance of relationship-building by either asking colleagues to teach them or offering to help them. This collaborative approach fosters trust and helps product managers learn from those around them, enhancing their effectiveness in their roles.
vocabulary_highlights: build relationships, earn trust, collaborative approach

speaker: Christian Idiodi
text: The holy grail of product work is really a reference customer. This is somebody that has used your solution or your product, loves it enough to tell people about it.
text_ko: 제품 작업의 성배는 사실상 레퍼런스 고객이에요. 이 고객은 당신의 솔루션이나 제품을 사용해보고, 그걸 정말 좋아해서 다른 사람들에게 추천해주는 사람이죠.
text_zh: 产品工作的圣杯实际上是一个参考客户。这是一个已经使用过你的解决方案或产品，并且非常喜欢，以至于愿意向他人推荐的人。
text_es: El santo grial del trabajo de producto es, en realidad, un cliente de referencia. Esta es una persona que ha utilizado tu solución o tu producto y lo ama lo suficiente como para recomendarlo a otros.
context: Lenny asks Christian about the most effective method for discovering what to build in product management. Christian highlights the importance of reference customers—those who not only use the product but also advocate for it to others. He underscores that reference customers are critical because their endorsement can significantly influence future customers and validate the product's value.
vocabulary_highlights: holy grail, reference customer, advocate

speaker: Christian Idiodi
text: You will get all the answers, the research, the failure, the mistakes, all the evidence. You know the difference between what people say, this is what they do.
text_ko: 모든 답변과 연구, 실패, 실수, 그리고 모든 증거를 얻게 될 거예요. 사람들이 하는 말과 실제 행동의 차이를 아는 게 중요해요.
text_zh: 你将获得所有的答案、研究、失败、错误和所有证据。你知道人们所说的与他们实际所做的之间的区别。
text_es: Obtendrás todas las respuestas, la investigación, los fracasos, los errores, toda la evidencia. Sabes la diferencia entre lo que la gente dice y lo que realmente hace.
context: In discussing the discovery process in product management, Christian emphasizes the importance of hands-on problem-solving over traditional research methods. He argues that direct engagement with customers will yield real insights and evidence about their needs, contrasting this with the often unreliable nature of what customers verbally express they want.
vocabulary_highlights: hands-on problem-solving, unreliable, evidence

speaker: Christina Wodtke
speaker_expertise: Product Management, Leadership Development, Product Design
text: I've seen so many companies do extremely well with it, and I would say that not all companies will be successful, period. Companies that are really successful with it are companies that... I think I can swear a little, they have their shit together.
text_ko: 많은 회사들이 그걸로 정말 잘 되는 걸 봤어요. 하지만 모든 회사가 성공할 수 있는 건 아니에요. 진짜 성공하는 회사들은... 솔직히 말하자면, 그들은 정말 잘 정리되어 있어요.
text_zh: 我看到很多公司在这方面表现非常出色，但我必须说，并不是所有公司都能成功。那些真正成功的公司，都是那些……我想我可以稍微直白一点，他们的管理非常到位。
text_es: He visto a muchas empresas tener un gran éxito con ello, y diría que no todas las empresas tendrán éxito, punto. Las empresas que realmente tienen éxito son aquellas que... creo que puedo decirlo de esta manera, tienen todo bajo control.
context: Lenny inquires about the impact of OKRs on companies and asks Christina to share insights on their effectiveness. Christina asserts that successful companies using OKRs have a solid foundation, including strategy and empowered teams. She emphasizes that OKRs should not be seen as a cure-all but rather as a tool that amplifies existing strengths.
vocabulary_highlights: have their shit together, supercharge, cure-all

speaker: Christina Wodtke
speaker_expertise: Product Management, Leadership Development, Product Design
text: I say OKRs are more of a vitamin, they're not a medicine. So, if you take OKRs and you're like, 'Oh, this will fix everything that's wrong with you.' No, that's not going to happen. It's just going to reveal everything that's wrong with your company.
text_ko: 저는 OKR이 비타민 같다고 생각해요. 약이 아니라는 거죠. 그래서 OKR을 도입하고 '이게 내 모든 문제를 해결해줄 거야'라고 생각하면 안 돼요. 그런 일은 일어나지 않아요. 오히려 회사의 문제점을 드러내줄 뿐이에요.
text_zh: 我认为OKR更像是一种维生素，而不是药物。如果你认为使用OKR就能解决你公司所有的问题，那是不可能的。它只是会揭示出你公司存在的所有问题。
text_es: Yo digo que los OKRs son más como una vitamina, no son una medicina. Así que, si tomas OKRs y piensas: 'Oh, esto solucionará todo lo que está mal contigo.' No, eso no va a suceder. Simplemente va a revelar todo lo que está mal en tu empresa.
context: Lenny wants to highlight the benefits of OKRs and how they can lead to organizational success. Christina illustrates that OKRs should be viewed as a preventative measure that enhances a company’s existing capabilities instead of a fix for underlying issues. She explains that instead of solving problems, OKRs will expose them, necessitating prior organizational health for effective implementation.
vocabulary_highlights: reveal, preventative measure, enhance

speaker: Christina Wodtke
speaker_expertise: Product Management, Leadership Development, Product Design
text: The main benefit is that there's a lot of concrete action through an OKR that you don't always get from strategy. Strategy tends to be a little longer, a little more Muji Muji.
text_ko: 주요 장점은 OKR을 통해 구체적인 행동이 많이 나온다는 거예요. 전략에서는 항상 그런 게 나오지 않거든요. 전략은 좀 더 긴 시간과 모호한 부분이 있는 것 같아요.
text_zh: 主要的好处在于，通过OKR（目标与关键结果）可以实现很多具体的行动，而这些在战略中并不总是能得到。战略往往比较长远，有些模糊。
text_es: El principal beneficio es que hay mucha acción concreta a través de un OKR (Objectives and Key Results) que no siempre se obtiene de la estrategia. La estrategia tiende a ser un poco más prolongada, un poco más abstracta.
context: Lenny asks Christina to summarize the primary benefits of using OKRs for organizations. Christina explains that OKRs provide actionable and measurable outcomes, while strategies can often be vague and abstract. By implementing OKRs, teams can establish concrete steps towards achieving their goals, thereby creating accountability and progress.
vocabulary_highlights: concrete action, Muji Muji, vague

speaker: Christina Wodtke
speaker_expertise: Product Management, Leadership Development, Product Design
text: One of the biggest problems founders struggle with is they don't scale very well, but if you can set a good OKR and get people to work on it, then you don't have to decide all those little IC tasks.
text_ko: 창업자들이 가장 힘들어하는 문제 중 하나는 잘 확장되지 않는다는 거예요. 하지만 좋은 OKR(목표 및 핵심 결과)을 설정하고 사람들이 그에 맞춰 일하게 하면, 작은 IC(개별 기여자) 작업들을 일일이 결정할 필요가 없어요.
text_zh: 创始人面临的最大问题之一是他们的扩展能力有限，但如果能够设定一个良好的OKR（目标与关键成果），并让团队围绕这个目标工作，那么就不必亲自决定所有的小的个体贡献（IC）任务。
text_es: Uno de los mayores problemas que enfrentan los fundadores es que no escalan muy bien, pero si puedes establecer un buen OKR (Objective and Key Results) y lograr que las personas trabajen en él, entonces no tendrás que decidir sobre todas esas pequeñas tareas individuales.
context: Lenny prompts Christina to discuss the advantages of OKRs in scaling organizations. Christina points out that an effective OKR framework allows leaders to focus on high-level objectives rather than micromanaging individual contributor tasks. This strategic approach helps in maintaining clarity and efficiency as a company grows.
vocabulary_highlights: scale, micromanaging, individual contributor

speaker: Christina Wodtke
speaker_expertise: Product Management, Leadership Development, Product Design
text: You have to think about, if somebody doesn't know what to do and you're like, 'Well, I have a strategy. I told you what my strategy is.' And they don't know how to make decisions, it means something's wrong with the strategy or you aren't being clear.
text_ko: 누군가 뭘 해야 할지 모른다면, '내가 전략이 있어. 내 전략이 뭐라고 했는지 말했잖아.'라고 해도 그 사람이 결정을 못 한다면, 그건 전략에 문제가 있거나 내가 명확하게 설명하지 않았다는 거예요.
text_zh: 你需要考虑，如果有人不知道该怎么做，而你说：“我有一个策略。我告诉过你我的策略是什么。”如果他们仍然无法做出决策，这就意味着策略可能存在问题，或者你没有表达清楚。
text_es: Debes considerar que si alguien no sabe qué hacer y tú dices: 'Bueno, tengo una estrategia. Te he explicado cuál es mi estrategia.' Y esa persona no sabe cómo tomar decisiones, significa que hay algo mal con la estrategia o que no estás siendo claro.
context: Lenny asks Christina about the root causes of issues that arise with OKRs. Christina explains that if team members are unclear about their tasks or objectives, it reflects a failure in communication or strategic clarity from leadership. This highlights the importance of transparent and effective communication in fostering a productive work environment.
vocabulary_highlights: strategic clarity, transparent, communication

speaker: Christina Wodtke
speaker_expertise: Product Management, Leadership Development, Product Design
text: You can either buy the obvious off-the-rack package like an NPS, or you can dig a little harder and figure out what would be meaningful to your company.
text_ko: 당연히 NPS 같은 뻔한 패키지를 사는 것도 좋지만, 조금 더 깊이 파고들어서 우리 회사에 진짜 의미 있는 게 뭔지 알아보는 것도 중요해요.
text_zh: 您可以选择购买像NPS这样的现成解决方案，或者深入挖掘，找出对您的公司真正有意义的内容。
text_es: Puedes optar por comprar un paquete estándar como un NPS, o puedes profundizar un poco más y descubrir qué sería realmente significativo para tu empresa.
context: Lenny discusses the challenges of measuring qualitative outcomes in product development. Christina encourages leaders to either utilize standard metrics like Net Promoter Score (NPS) or invest time in understanding what metrics would provide meaningful insights specific to their company. This underscores the importance of tailored measurement strategies to accurately assess user satisfaction and product impact.
vocabulary_highlights: off-the-rack, meaningful insights, tailored measurement

speaker: Christine Itwaru
text: Speaking as a former PM, I would not ever give up spending time with customers and watching their pain. That's how I fell in love with product was I saw my internal customer 12 years back now fighting with the keyboard, fighting with the mouse, and I was just like, 'Oh, my gosh. What's this guy doing?'
text_ko: 전 총리로서 말씀드리자면, 고객과 시간을 보내고 그들의 어려움을 지켜보는 걸 절대 포기하지 않을 거예요. 제가 제품에 사랑에 빠진 이유도 12년 전 내부 고객이 키보드와 마우스와 씨름하는 모습을 보면서였어요. 그때 '이 사람은 도대체 뭐하고 있는 거지?'라는 생각이 들었거든요.
text_zh: 作为一名前总理，我绝不会放弃与客户交流和观察他们的痛点。正是因为我在12年前看到我的内部客户与键盘和鼠标斗争，我才爱上了产品。当时我心里想：“天哪，这家伙在干什么？”
text_es: Hablando como un ex primer ministro, nunca renunciaría a pasar tiempo con los clientes y observar sus dificultades. Así fue como me enamoré del producto; hace 12 años vi a mi cliente interno luchando con el teclado y el mouse, y pensé: 'Oh, Dios mío. ¿Qué está haciendo este tipo?'
context: Christine shares her perspective on the importance of understanding customer experiences as a product manager. She emphasizes that spending time observing customers and their frustrations is crucial for a product manager to develop empathy and a passion for improving the product. This connection to customer pain points is essential for creating effective and valuable products.
vocabulary_highlights: spending time with customers, internal customer, fell in love with product

speaker: Christine Itwaru
text: One is it is a thing you do. Product operations for a VP or a head of product or a product manager is the creation of some system that allows you to thrive or allows your team to thrive in product management.
text_ko: 하나는 네가 하는 일이에요. VP나 제품 책임자, 제품 매니저의 제품 운영(product operations)은 팀이 제품 관리에서 잘할 수 있도록 도와주는 시스템을 만드는 거예요.
text_zh: 产品运营对于副总裁、产品负责人或产品经理来说，是建立一个系统，使你或你的团队在产品管理中能够蓬勃发展。
text_es: Una de las claves es que se trata de una actividad que realizas. Las operaciones de producto para un VP (Vicepresidente), un líder de producto o un gerente de producto consisten en la creación de un sistema que te permita prosperar o que permita a tu equipo sobresalir en la gestión de productos.
context: Christine defines the essence of product operations, explaining that it involves establishing systems that support product managers and their teams. This definition highlights how product operations can be seen both as a set of activities and as a role that enhances the functioning of product management within an organization. Her insight emphasizes the strategic importance of creating a supportive environment for product teams.
vocabulary_highlights: creation of some system, allows your team to thrive

speaker: Christine Itwaru
text: There was a lot of pain around internal alignment in general, transparency to stakeholders up across your revenue team members. Then for a lot of people during this time, growth was a massive propeller of the need for product ops.
text_ko: 내부 정렬이 잘 안 되고, 이해관계자들에게 투명성을 유지하는 게 힘든 상황이 많았어요. 그리고 이 시기에 많은 사람들에게 성장이라는 게 제품 운영(product ops)의 필요성을 크게 부추겼죠.
text_zh: 在内部协调方面普遍存在许多问题，透明度对利益相关者以及收入团队成员至关重要。在这个时期，对许多人来说，增长成为了推动产品运营（product ops）需求的主要动力。
text_es: Hubo mucho dolor en torno a la alineación interna en general y la transparencia hacia los interesados (stakeholders) entre los miembros de su equipo de ingresos. Para muchas personas durante este tiempo, el crecimiento fue un gran impulsor de la necesidad de operaciones de producto (product ops).
context: Christine discusses the growing necessity for product operations in response to challenges such as lack of internal alignment and transparency among stakeholders. She points out that as companies experience growth, the complexity of managing product development increases, leading to a heightened demand for structured product operations to facilitate better communication and collaboration within teams.
vocabulary_highlights: pain around internal alignment, massive propeller, transparency to stakeholders

speaker: Christine Itwaru
text: So, there was a lack of alignment across again, they knew it was coming, they just didn't know the extent of what to expect and how to prepare customers or prospects or the change the way that we should have.
text_ko: 다시 말해, 조율이 부족했어요. 그들은 이런 상황이 올 거라는 걸 알았지만, 얼마나 심각할지, 고객이나 잠재 고객을 어떻게 준비시켜야 할지에 대한 준비가 부족했죠.
text_zh: 因此，各方之间缺乏一致性，他们知道这个问题即将出现，但并不知道具体的影响程度，也不清楚如何准备客户或潜在客户，或如何以应有的方式进行变革。
text_es: Hubo una falta de alineación nuevamente; sabían que se avecinaba, pero no conocían la magnitud de lo que debían esperar ni cómo preparar a los clientes o prospectos, ni cómo gestionar el cambio de la manera adecuada.
context: Christine reflects on a poorly executed product launch that highlighted the need for better communication and alignment within the organization. She notes that while the product team was aware of the upcoming changes, there was insufficient clarity on how to effectively prepare both internal teams and customers for the transition. This situation underlines the importance of establishing clear communication channels in product operations.
vocabulary_highlights: lack of alignment, extent of what to expect, prepare customers

speaker: Christine Itwaru
text: I think maybe that is because I have a product background. So, I felt that pain very acutely, but I will say for the majority of people I always speak to who don't have that product background, they're coming from consulting or from technical success or from some other group marketing maybe, it does feel relatively new because they're starting to dive into that space a little bit.
text_ko: 저는 제품 배경이 있어서 그런 것 같아요. 그래서 그 고통을 정말 잘 느꼈는데, 대부분 제가 이야기하는 분들은 제품 배경이 없고 컨설팅이나 기술 쪽에서 성공을 거둔 분들이 많아요. 그분들은 마케팅 쪽에서도 올 수 있고, 그런 분들에게는 이 분야가 상대적으로 새롭게 느껴질 거예요. 왜냐하면 이제 막 그 영역에 발을 들여놓기 시작하니까요.
text_zh: 我认为这可能是因为我有产品背景。因此，我对这种痛点感受得非常深刻。不过，我必须说，大多数我交谈的人没有产品背景，他们来自咨询、技术成功或其他市场营销领域，确实会觉得这相对较新，因为他们开始逐渐深入这个领域。
text_es: Creo que eso se debe a que tengo un trasfondo en productos (product background). Por lo tanto, sentí ese dolor de manera muy aguda, pero debo decir que para la mayoría de las personas con las que siempre hablo, que no tienen ese trasfondo en productos, vienen de consultoría (consulting) o de éxito técnico (technical success) o de algún otro grupo de marketing, se siente relativamente nuevo porque están comenzando a adentrarse un poco en ese espacio.
context: Christine shares her perspective on the evolving understanding of product operations, noting that for individuals without a product management background, the concept may seem novel. She attributes her deep understanding of product operations to her own experience in product management, while acknowledging that those from other fields may find the transition into product ops more challenging, as they familiarize themselves with new responsibilities and frameworks.
vocabulary_highlights: product background, felt that pain acutely, dive into that space

speaker: Christine Itwaru
text: I keep mentioning that more mature product ops folks end up being a very good strategic advisor to leaders in product and to the product teams and that continues to be my belief.
text_ko: 저는 성숙한 제품 운영(Product Ops) 전문가들이 제품 리더와 팀에게 훌륭한 전략적 조언자가 된다고 계속 강조하고 있어요. 이건 제 믿음이 계속해서 변하지 않아요.
text_zh: 我一直提到，经验更丰富的产品运营人员最终会成为产品领导者和产品团队的优秀战略顾问，这也是我始终坚信的观点。
text_es: Sigo mencionando que los profesionales de operaciones de producto (product ops) más experimentados se convierten en excelentes asesores estratégicos para los líderes de producto y para los equipos de producto, y esa sigue siendo mi convicción.
context: Christine asserts that as product operations roles mature, individuals in these positions become valuable strategic advisors to product leaders and teams. This evolution highlights the potential for product ops to not only streamline processes but also to influence strategic decision-making within organizations, showcasing the importance of this role in driving overall business success.
vocabulary_highlights: mature product ops folks, strategic advisor, influence strategic decision-making

speaker: Christopher Lochhead
text: If you are somebody for whom you want to make an exponential difference, you want to innovate, you want to create new value where there wasn't, you want to have a legendary career where you could look back on your career and go, you know what? I was part of this and that, and I was on this team, now's the greatest time in history. And what I would say to you is, the future needs you.
text_ko: 당신이 정말로 큰 변화를 만들고 싶고, 혁신하고, 새로운 가치를 창출하고 싶다면, 그리고 나중에 돌아봤을 때 "내가 이 팀의 일원이었고, 저런 일도 했었지"라고 자랑스럽게 말할 수 있는 전설적인 커리어를 원한다면, 지금이 역사상 가장 좋은 시점이에요. 제가 하고 싶은 말은, 미래는 당신이 필요하다는 거예요.
text_zh: 如果你希望创造显著的影响，想要创新，想要在原本没有的地方创造新价值，想要拥有一个传奇的职业生涯，回首往事时能够自豪地说：“我参与了这个和那个，我在这个团队中。”那么，现在是历史上最好的时机。我想对你说的是，未来需要你。
text_es: Si eres alguien que desea hacer una diferencia exponencial, que quiere innovar, crear nuevo valor donde antes no existía, y tener una carrera legendaria de la cual puedas mirar atrás y decir: "Yo formé parte de esto y aquello, y estuve en este equipo", ahora es el mejor momento en la historia. Y lo que te diría es que el futuro te necesita.
context: Lenny asks Chris to share his thoughts on the current landscape for creators and entrepreneurs. Chris emphasizes that today is an unprecedented time for innovation and entrepreneurship, encouraging individuals to pursue their passions and make a significant impact. He highlights the importance of working on exponential changes rather than incremental improvements.
vocabulary_highlights: exponential difference, legendary career, create new value

speaker: Christopher Lochhead
text: The decision they make is, 'What I'm going to do, is I am going to compete in a market with demand, with a better product/service/brand, maybe a better business model.' And when the world gets my better, the world will beat a path to my door.
text_ko: 그들이 내리는 결정은 '내가 할 일은 수요가 있는 시장에서 더 나은 제품/서비스/브랜드, 어쩌면 더 나은 비즈니스 모델로 경쟁하는 거야.' 라는 거예요. 그리고 세상이 내 더 나은 걸 알게 되면, 사람들이 내 문 앞에 줄을 설 거예요.
text_zh: 他们做出的决定是：“我将要做的是，在有需求的市场中，凭借更好的产品/服务/品牌，甚至可能是更好的商业模式进行竞争。”当世界看到我的优势时，必定会主动找上我。
text_es: La decisión que toman es: "Lo que voy a hacer es competir en un mercado con demanda, con un mejor producto/servicio/marca, tal vez con un mejor modelo de negocio." Y cuando el mundo reconozca mi superioridad, vendrá a buscarme.
context: Chris discusses a common mindset among entrepreneurs where they choose to compete in established markets instead of creating new categories. He points out that many mistakenly believe that having a superior product or service will guarantee success. This mindset often leads to fierce competition for a small share of the market rather than innovating and defining a new market space.
vocabulary_highlights: better product/service/brand, beat a path to my door

speaker: Christopher Lochhead
text: Nobody legendary ever did that. Not a one. We all know who Bob Marley is. We don't know who the 17th greatest reggae musician or band in the world is.
text_ko: 전설적인 사람은 그런 걸 하지 않았어요. 한 명도 없죠. 우리 모두 밥 말리(Bob Marley)가 누구인지 아는 반면, 세계에서 17위의 레게(Reggae) 뮤지션이나 밴드가 누구인지 아는 사람은 없어요.
text_zh: 没有人能做到这一点，传奇人物更是没有。我们都知道鲍勃·马利（Bob Marley）是谁，但我们却不知道世界上第十七位最伟大的雷鬼（reggae）音乐家或乐队是谁。
text_es: Nadie legendario hizo eso. Ni uno solo. Todos sabemos quién es Bob Marley. No sabemos quién es el 17º mejor músico o banda de reggae en el mundo.
context: Chris argues that the most admired figures in various fields, including business and arts, are those who have created new categories rather than competing within existing ones. He uses Bob Marley as an example of a legendary artist who stands out because he defined his own category, while the lesser-known figures remain largely forgotten. This underscores the significance of category design in achieving lasting recognition.
vocabulary_highlights: legendary, created new categories

speaker: Christopher Lochhead
text: You either stay in your niche and get diminished over time, or you uplevel and you go to play for the whole enchilada.
text_ko: 너는 네 틀 안에 머물면서 점점 작아지거나, 아니면 한 단계 업그레이드해서 모든 것을 다 잡으러 나가야 해요.
text_zh: 要么你固守自己的细分市场，随着时间的推移逐渐被边缘化，要么你提升自己，争取更大的市场份额。
text_es: Te quedas en tu nicho y te vas desvaneciendo con el tiempo, o te elevas y juegas por el todo.
context: Chris explains the choices available to companies once they find initial success in a niche market. He warns that staying confined to a niche can lead to stagnation, while expanding to capture the broader market ('the whole enchilada') can lead to significant growth. This highlights the importance of evolving beyond initial success to maintain relevance and competitiveness.
vocabulary_highlights: uplevel, the whole enchilada

speaker: Christopher Lochhead
text: Problems create categories, and you either have to A, solve a new problem, or B, reframe, name and claim an existing problem in a different way.
text_ko: 문제는 카테고리를 만들어줘요. 그래서 당신은 A, 새로운 문제를 해결하거나 B, 기존의 문제를 다른 방식으로 재정의하고 이름을 붙여야 해요.
text_zh: 问题创造了类别，你要么选择A，解决一个新问题，要么选择B，以不同的方式重新定义、命名并认领一个现有的问题。
text_es: Los problemas generan categorías, y tienes que A, resolver un nuevo problema, o B, replantear, nombrar y reivindicar un problema existente de una manera diferente.
context: Chris discusses the fundamental relationship between problems and categories in business. He emphasizes that successful companies either solve a new problem or creatively reframe an existing one. This insight is crucial for entrepreneurs seeking to innovate and differentiate themselves in the market.
vocabulary_highlights: reframe, name and claim, create categories

speaker: Christopher Lochhead
text: Thinking about thinking is the most important kind of thinking.
text_ko: 생각하는 방법에 대해 생각하는 게 가장 중요한 생각이에요.
text_zh: 思考思考是最重要的思维方式。
text_es: Reflexionar sobre cómo pensamos es el tipo de pensamiento más importante.
context: Chris introduces the concept of 'thinking about thinking' as a foundational principle in category design. He suggests that entrepreneurs must reflect critically on their thought processes and assumptions to foster innovative thinking. This approach encourages breaking free from conventional mindsets to cultivate unique and impactful ideas.
vocabulary_highlights: thinking about thinking, foundational principle

speaker: Christopher Lochhead
text: If you're lucky enough to make it to the top of a mountain, throw down a fucking rope.
text_ko: 산 정상에 오를 수 있다면, 꼭 밑에 있는 사람들에게 도움의 줄을 던져줘요.
text_zh: 如果你有幸登上了山顶，就要伸出援手。
text_es: Si tienes la suerte de llegar a la cima de una montaña, tiende una cuerda.
context: Chris shares a personal motto that emphasizes the importance of helping others once you've achieved success. He underscores the value of mentorship and support, especially for those who face challenges. This message resonates with the theme of community and collaboration in the entrepreneurial journey.
vocabulary_highlights: throw down a rope

speaker: Chris Miller
speaker_expertise: Growth Strategy, Product Management, AI/ML Products
text: That attitude of saying that every problem is our problem and radical accountability and ownership mentality helped us find opportunities that maybe the business wasn't explicitly asking us to solve, but we were able to triangulate why it might be important for the business for us to solve it.
text_ko: 모든 문제는 우리 문제라고 생각하고, 철저한 책임감과 주인의식을 가지는 태도가 우리에게 비즈니스가 명시적으로 요구하지 않았던 기회를 찾는 데 큰 도움이 됐어요. 우리가 왜 그 문제를 해결하는 게 비즈니스에 중요할 수 있는지를 잘 파악할 수 있었거든요.
text_zh: 这种将每个问题视为我们自己问题的态度，以及激进的责任感和主人翁意识，帮助我们发现了一些业务可能并没有明确要求我们解决的机会，但我们能够推测出这些问题对业务的重要性。
text_es: Esa actitud de considerar que cada problema es nuestro problema, junto con una mentalidad de responsabilidad radical y de propiedad, nos ayudó a identificar oportunidades que tal vez el negocio no nos estaba pidiendo explícitamente que resolviéramos, pero pudimos triangular por qué podría ser importante para la empresa que nosotros lo solucionáramos.
context: Lenny asks Chris about the early success factors that helped HubSpot grow. Chris explains how their growth team's mentality of radical accountability—taking ownership of problems regardless of whether they were assigned to them—allowed them to identify and address opportunities that were not initially prioritized by the business. This proactive approach helped them contribute significantly to the company's growth.
vocabulary_highlights: radical accountability, triangulate, explicitly asking

speaker: Chris Miller
speaker_expertise: Growth Strategy, Product Management, AI/ML Products
text: We intentionally put out a lot of free software, and the idea is that this software is not sort of gimmicky. It's not designed to run out of value on day one. It's actually designed so that our smallest customers can get some value out of it in a sustainable way.
text_ko: 우리는 의도적으로 많은 무료 소프트웨어를 제공해요. 이 소프트웨어는 단순한 gimmick이 아니고, 첫날부터 가치가 떨어지도록 설계된 게 아니에요. 오히려 가장 작은 고객들도 지속 가능한 방식으로 가치를 얻을 수 있도록 만들어졌어요.
text_zh: 我们故意推出了大量免费的软件，这些软件并不是花哨的 gimmicky 产品。它们并不是在第一天就失去价值，而是旨在让我们最小的客户以可持续的方式获得一些实际的价值。
text_es: Nosotros lanzamos intencionadamente una gran cantidad de software gratuito, y la idea es que este software no sea simplemente un truco (gimmick). No está diseñado para perder su valor desde el primer día. En realidad, está concebido para que nuestros clientes más pequeños puedan obtener un valor sostenible de él.
context: Lenny inquires about HubSpot's approach to product-led growth. Chris discusses their strategy of offering free software that provides genuine value to users, rather than being a gimmick that quickly loses its appeal. This approach aims to engage users meaningfully, prompting them to upgrade as they see the product's benefits.
vocabulary_highlights: gimmicky, sustainable way, genuine value

speaker: Chris Miller
speaker_expertise: Growth Strategy, Product Management, AI/ML Products
text: One of the traits that I look for in PMs that I hire onto my teams... is relentless curiosity, this insatiable desire to understand things and a lack of fear in admitting when they don't understand things.
text_ko: 제가 팀에 채용하는 PM들에게서 찾는 특성 중 하나는 바로 끈질긴 호기심이에요. 이해하고자 하는 끝없는 욕구와 모르는 걸 인정하는 데 두려움이 없는 태도죠.
text_zh: 我在招聘项目经理（PM）时，最看重的特质之一就是他们对事物的无尽好奇心，以及在不理解时毫不畏惧地承认自己的不足。
text_es: Una de las características que busco en los PMs (Project Managers) que contrato para mis equipos es una curiosidad incesante, ese deseo insaciable de comprender las cosas y la falta de miedo para admitir cuando no entienden algo.
context: Lenny asks Chris about the key traits he values in product managers. Chris emphasizes that relentless curiosity is crucial, as it enables PMs to seek understanding and admit gaps in their knowledge. This trait fosters a culture of learning and innovation within teams, allowing them to address complex challenges effectively.
vocabulary_highlights: relentless curiosity, insatiable desire, admitting

speaker: Chris Miller
speaker_expertise: Growth Strategy, Product Management, AI/ML Products
text: If you're doing product-led growth the right way, then you're trying to balance the science and sort of taking a somewhat hygienic approach to validating assumptions and hypotheses with being really ambitious.
text_ko: 제품 주도 성장(product-led growth)을 제대로 하고 있다면, 과학적인 접근을 통해 가설과 가정을 검증하는 것과 동시에 야망을 가지고 균형을 맞추려고 노력하고 있는 거예요.
text_zh: 如果你在正确地进行产品驱动增长（product-led growth），那么你应该在科学性和以一种相对规范的方式验证假设之间找到平衡，同时保持雄心壮志。
text_es: Si estás implementando el crecimiento impulsado por el producto (product-led growth) de la manera correcta, estás tratando de equilibrar la parte científica y adoptando un enfoque bastante metódico para validar supuestos e hipótesis, al mismo tiempo que mantienes una gran ambición.
context: Lenny asks Chris about the balance required in product-led growth strategies. Chris explains that successful product-led growth involves a careful balance of scientific rigor and ambition—validating ideas through data while still pushing for impactful innovations. This approach helps teams avoid stagnation while ensuring decisions are data-informed.
vocabulary_highlights: hygienic approach, validating assumptions, impactful innovations

speaker: Chris Miller
speaker_expertise: Growth Strategy, Product Management, AI/ML Products
