text: It wasn't until I got my second product management job where it really was an inflection point, where I was like, 'Oh, got it. This is what this is supposed to look and feel like.'
text_ko: 두 번째 제품 관리 직업을 얻었을 때 진짜 전환점이 왔어요. 그때서야 '아, 이게 진짜 이런 느낌이구나' 하고 깨달았어요.
text_zh: 直到我获得第二份产品管理（product management）工作时，我才真正意识到这是一个转折点，那时我心里想：“哦，明白了。这就是它应该呈现和感受的样子。”
text_es: No fue hasta que conseguí mi segundo trabajo en gestión de productos (product management) que realmente fue un punto de inflexión, donde pensé: 'Ah, ya lo entendí. Así es como se supone que debe lucir y sentirse esto.'
context: Lenny inquires about Chris's career journey in product management. Chris reflects on how his second role marked a pivotal moment in his career, where he finally grasped the essence of product management by working closely with users and utilizing data to drive decisions. This experience transformed his understanding and approach to the field.
vocabulary_highlights: inflection point, grasped the essence, utilizing data

speaker: Chris Miller
speaker_expertise: Growth Strategy, Product Management, AI/ML Products
text: If you're a smaller team, you kind of have an acute understanding of the pain points that are like today's buyers that you need to put out.
text_ko: 작은 팀이라면 요즘 구매자들이 겪는 문제점들에 대해 더 잘 이해하고 있을 거예요. 그걸 해결해줘야 하니까요.
text_zh: 如果你是一个小团队，你对当今买家的痛点有着深刻的理解，这些痛点是你需要解决的。
text_es: Si eres un equipo más pequeño, tienes una comprensión aguda de los puntos de dolor que enfrentan los compradores actuales que necesitas abordar.
context: Lenny discusses the importance of understanding customer pain points in product-led growth. Chris suggests that smaller teams often have a better grasp of the challenges faced by contemporary buyers. Recognizing these pain points allows companies to tailor their solutions more effectively, enhancing customer engagement and satisfaction.
vocabulary_highlights: acute understanding, pain points, contemporary buyers

speaker: Claire Butler
text: So much of what we were doing was influenced by gut, by trying to connect with people, listening to them. But when I look back is when I'm like, 'Oh, this is a repeatable motion.' So when I look back at it, I would say that if I were to define and think about how I define our go-to-market motion, and we've said it, we've called it a lot of things over time. We called it product-led, we called it community-led. The way I think about it now is this bottoms-up motion, that really is focused on ICs.
text_ko: 우리가 했던 많은 일들이 직감에 의존하고, 사람들과 연결하려고 하고, 그들의 이야기를 듣는 데서 영향을 받았어요. 그런데 돌아보면 '아, 이건 반복할 수 있는 동작이구나'라고 느껴요. 그래서 우리가 시장에 나가는 방식을 정의하고 생각해보면, 시간이 지나면서 여러 가지로 불렀던 것 같아요. 제품 주도(product-led)라고도 했고, 커뮤니티 주도(community-led)라고도 했죠. 지금은 이게 아래에서 위로 올라오는(bottoms-up) 방식이라고 생각해요. 정말로 개인 기여자(ICs)에 초점을 맞추고 있거든요.
text_zh: 我们所做的很多事情都是受到直觉的影响，试图与人建立联系，倾听他们的声音。但当我回顾时，我意识到这其实是一个可重复的过程。因此，当我回顾这一点时，我会说，如果要定义我们的市场进入策略（go-to-market motion），我会说我们曾经用过很多不同的称呼，比如以产品为主导（product-led），以社区为主导（community-led）。现在我认为这是一种自下而上的策略（bottoms-up motion），真正关注的是个体贡献者（ICs）。
text_es: Mucho de lo que hacíamos estaba influenciado por la intuición, por el intento de conectar con las personas y escucharlas. Pero al mirar hacia atrás, me doy cuenta de que esto es un movimiento repetible. Así que, al reflexionar sobre ello, diría que si tuviera que definir y pensar en cómo defino nuestra estrategia de entrada al mercado (go-to-market motion), hemos utilizado muchos términos a lo largo del tiempo. Lo hemos llamado liderado por el producto (product-led), liderado por la comunidad (community-led). La forma en que lo veo ahora es como un enfoque de abajo hacia arriba (bottoms-up motion), que realmente se centra en los contribuyentes individuales (ICs).
context: Lenny asks Claire to explain what a bottom-up go-to-market motion is and how it applies to Figma. Claire clarifies that this approach emphasizes individual contributors (ICs) who spend significant time using the product. She reflects on how their strategy has evolved, mentioning that their focus has shifted from gut feelings to creating a repeatable process that resonates with users, particularly designers, who are central to their market.
vocabulary_highlights: influenced by gut, repeatable motion, product-led, community-led

speaker: Claire Butler
text: One of the things that I did was really try to not market. And that's so funny as a marketer to say that, but that was really core to build authenticity with people. And so the way that we did that in the early days was what we had was the tool, and that's pretty much what we had, and we had a design team and we had an engineering team.
text_ko: 제가 했던 것 중 하나는 마케팅을 하지 않으려고 정말 노력한 거예요. 마케터로서 그 말을 하는 게 참 웃기지만, 그게 사람들과의 진정성을 쌓는 데 정말 중요했어요. 그래서 초창기에는 우리가 가진 도구와 디자인 팀, 엔지니어링 팀이 전부였어요.
text_zh: 我所做的其中一件事就是尽量不进行营销。作为一名市场营销人员，这听起来很有趣，但这确实是与人建立真实性的核心所在。在早期，我们的做法就是依靠我们手中的工具，这几乎就是我们所有的资源，还有一个设计团队和一个工程团队。
text_es: Una de las cosas que hice fue realmente tratar de no hacer marketing. Y es curioso decir eso siendo un especialista en marketing, pero fue fundamental para construir autenticidad con las personas. Así que la forma en que lo hicimos en los primeros días fue con la herramienta que teníamos, que era prácticamente lo único que teníamos, además de un equipo de diseño y un equipo de ingeniería.
context: Claire discusses her approach to building credibility for Figma in the early days, highlighting that designers are often skeptical of marketing. She emphasizes the importance of authenticity and how she focused on showcasing the technical features of the product rather than traditional marketing tactics. By collaborating closely with the design and engineering teams, Figma aimed to create genuine connections with early users, which helped build trust.
vocabulary_highlights: build authenticity, core to build, traditional marketing, technical features

speaker: Claire Butler
text: So, we have a couple tiers. We have a free tier and then we have a pro tier, and then we have our org tier. And the free tier, free tier includes this free starter team. And so you can just do that, go to figma.com, and go do that. Pro is all enter credit card, and then org is you talk to sales.
text_ko: 우리는 몇 가지 요금제가 있어요. 무료 요금제와 프로 요금제, 그리고 조직 요금제가 있죠. 무료 요금제에는 무료 스타터 팀이 포함되어 있어요. 그래서 그냥 figma.com에 가서 시작하면 돼요. 프로 요금제는 신용카드를 입력해야 하고, 조직 요금제는 영업팀과 이야기해야 해요.
text_zh: 我们有几个层级。首先是免费层级，然后是专业层级，最后是组织层级。免费层级包括一个免费的入门团队。您只需访问 figma.com 就可以注册。专业层级需要输入信用卡信息，而组织层级则需要与销售团队联系。
text_es: Tenemos varios niveles. Tenemos un nivel gratuito, un nivel profesional y un nivel para organizaciones. El nivel gratuito incluye un equipo inicial sin costo. Así que puedes simplemente ir a figma.com y registrarte. El nivel profesional requiere ingresar los datos de la tarjeta de crédito, y para el nivel de organizaciones, debes comunicarte con ventas.
context: Lenny inquires about Figma's pricing structure and how it impacts user adoption. Claire explains the different tiers of Figma's service, highlighting the importance of the free tier as an entry point for users. She mentions that the free tier allows for a starter team without immediate payment, which encourages users to explore the product and build confidence before committing to the paid tiers.
vocabulary_highlights: credit card, starter team, entry point, user adoption

speaker: Claire Butler
text: I think that one of the ... I don't know about requirements, but things that makes this a lot more likely to be successful, is that your IC, there's a tool, and they can use it on their own. And it's technical. I think that helps a ton.
text_ko: 성공 가능성을 높이는 중요한 요소 중 하나는 IC가 사용할 수 있는 도구가 있다는 거예요. 그리고 그 도구가 기술적이라는 점이 큰 도움이 된다고 생각해요.
text_zh: 我认为，使这项工作更有可能成功的一个因素是，您的IC（Individual Contributor，个人贡献者）有一个工具，并且他们可以独立使用。这个工具是技术性的，我认为这非常有帮助。
text_es: Creo que una de las cosas que hace que esto tenga muchas más probabilidades de ser exitoso, es que tu IC (Individual Contributor) tiene una herramienta que puede usar de manera autónoma. Y es técnica. Creo que eso ayuda muchísimo.
context: Claire reflects on the prerequisites for successfully implementing a bottoms-up go-to-market strategy. She emphasizes that a technical product that individual contributors (ICs) can use independently increases the likelihood of success. This autonomy allows users to build confidence in the product, which is crucial for fostering adoption within organizations.
vocabulary_highlights: prerequisites, implementing, autonomy, fostering adoption

speaker: Claire Butler
text: I think the key thing is that you have to keep doing it. One of the things that I feel like, at my role now at Figma, that I think a lot about, is how I can keep advocating for this stuff when we are starting to implement more top down motion, and having to really prove ROI.
text_ko: 가장 중요한 건 계속해서 해나가는 거라고 생각해요. 지금 Figma에서 제 역할을 하면서 많이 고민하는 것 중 하나는, 위에서 아래로 진행되는 방식이 많아질 때도 이런 것들에 대해 계속 옹호할 수 있는 방법이 뭐가 있을까 하는 거예요. 그리고 ROI를 확실히 증명해야 하는 상황에서도 말이죠.
text_zh: 我认为关键在于持续努力。我在Figma的工作中常常思考的一件事是，在我们开始实施更多自上而下的策略，并且需要真正证明投资回报率（ROI）时，我如何能够继续为这些事情发声。
text_es: Creo que lo más importante es que debes seguir haciéndolo. Una de las cosas en las que pienso mucho en mi rol actual en Figma es cómo puedo seguir abogando por esto cuando comenzamos a implementar un enfoque más de arriba hacia abajo (top down), y realmente tener que demostrar el retorno de la inversión (ROI).
context: Claire discusses how Figma's growth necessitates a balance between maintaining the successful bottoms-up approach while integrating more traditional top-down strategies. She highlights the importance of continuous advocacy for the core values and methodologies that initially drove Figma's success, even as the company scales and faces new challenges.
vocabulary_highlights: advocating, top down motion, prove ROI, continuous advocacy

speaker: Claire Butler
text: I remember there was a specific instance, I think it was last year, maybe two years ago, where there was this issue with these servers and an AWS cluster went down and we didn't know what was going on. And so we had downtime multiple times in a week and people were pissed, right? Things were not going well.
text_ko: 작년인가 재작년인가, 서버 문제 때문에 AWS 클러스터가 다운된 적이 있었던 것 같아요. 그때 상황이 어떻게 된 건지 전혀 몰랐고, 그래서 일주일에 여러 번 다운타임이 발생했어요. 그때 사람들이 정말 화났었죠. 일이 잘 안 풀리고 있었어요.
text_zh: 我记得有一个具体的例子，我想是去年，或者两年前，发生了一些服务器的问题，AWS集群（AWS cluster）宕机了，我们不知道发生了什么。因此，我们一周内多次出现了停机时间，大家都很不满，情况并不理想。
text_es: Recuerdo que hubo un caso específico, creo que fue el año pasado, tal vez hace dos años, donde hubo un problema con unos servidores y un clúster de AWS se cayó y no sabíamos qué estaba pasando. Tuvimos tiempos de inactividad varias veces en una semana y la gente estaba molesta, ¿verdad? Las cosas no estaban yendo bien.
context: Claire recounts a challenging experience at Figma involving server downtime and the subsequent backlash from users. She emphasizes the importance of transparency during crises and how the team chose to publicly address the issues. By openly communicating with users, Figma aimed to maintain trust and demonstrate accountability, which is essential for sustaining user relationships.
vocabulary_highlights: transparency, backlash, publicly address, sustaining relationships

speaker: Claire Hughes Johnson
text: If you're not sure who the decision maker is, one, it's probably you. And I'd rather you act that way than not because you're going to slow the whole company down. Follow a process and get it done, and don't forget to actually make a decision.
text_ko: 결정권자가 누구인지 잘 모르겠다면, 아마도 그게 당신일 거예요. 그런 역할을 하는 게 더 낫고, 그렇지 않으면 회사 전체가 느려질 거예요. 과정을 따라가고 일을 마무리 짓는 게 중요해요. 그리고 실제로 결정을 내리는 걸 잊지 마세요.
text_zh: 如果你不确定谁是决策者，首先，很可能就是你。我宁愿你以决策者的身份行事，而不是不作为，因为这会拖慢整个公司的进程。遵循流程，完成任务，别忘了真正做出决策。
text_es: Si no estás seguro de quién es el tomador de decisiones, probablemente seas tú. Y prefiero que actúes como tal en lugar de no hacerlo, porque eso solo va a ralentizar a toda la empresa. Sigue un proceso, concluye y no olvides tomar una decisión.
context: Lenny asks Claire for her insights on decision-making within a company. Claire emphasizes the importance of taking initiative in decision-making, suggesting that many employees often overlook their own authority. She encourages individuals to actively engage in the decision-making process, as hesitance can hinder company progress and momentum.
vocabulary_highlights: decision maker, slow the whole company down, follow a process, positive momentum

speaker: Claire Hughes Johnson
text: If you believe that talent is everything, then your hiring process is everything. So yes, you do need to put that work in.
text_ko: 재능이 전부라고 생각한다면, 채용 과정도 정말 중요해요. 그러니까 그 부분에 신경 써야 해요.
text_zh: 如果你认为人才是最重要的，那么你的招聘流程就是一切。因此，确实需要在这方面下功夫。
text_es: Si crees que el talento lo es todo, entonces tu proceso de contratación es fundamental. Así que sí, necesitas dedicarle ese esfuerzo.
context: Lenny inquires about the significance of the hiring process. Claire asserts that if a company's success hinges on talent, then the hiring process must be meticulously crafted and executed. She reinforces the idea that investing time and effort in refining hiring practices is essential for building a strong team and ultimately achieving company goals.
vocabulary_highlights: talent is everything, hiring process, meticulously crafted, executed

speaker: Claire Hughes Johnson
text: You have the supporting beam. Say it's a post and beam structure. You need the posts and the beams, and then you're going to have to do the mechanicals, right? There's going to have to be some amount of wiring in order for you... I think of putting in the posts and beams and the mechanicals and the foundation as actually essential to scale.
text_ko: 지지 기둥이 필요해요. 예를 들어, 포스트 앤 빔(post and beam) 구조라면 기둥과 보가 필요하고, 그 다음에 기계적인 부분도 신경 써야 해요. 전선 같은 것도 어느 정도 필요할 거고요. 저는 기둥과 보, 기계적 요소, 그리고 기초를 세우는 게 실제로 확장(scale)하는 데 필수적이라고 생각해요.
text_zh: 您需要支撑梁。假设这是一个柱梁结构，您需要柱子和梁，然后还需要进行机械安装，对吧？为了实现这一点，必须进行一定程度的布线。我认为安装柱子、梁、机械设备和基础对于实现规模化是至关重要的。
text_es: Tienes la viga de soporte. Digamos que es una estructura de postes y vigas. Necesitas los postes y las vigas, y luego tendrás que hacer la parte mecánica, ¿verdad? Va a tener que haber cierta cantidad de cableado para que tú... Pienso que la instalación de los postes, las vigas, los sistemas mecánicos y la fundación es realmente esencial para escalar.
context: Lenny prompts Claire to elaborate on her metaphor of a house structure in relation to company building. Claire explains that just like a house requires a sturdy foundation and support beams, a company also needs essential structures and processes in place to ensure scalability. This includes foundational documents and operational systems that facilitate growth and stability.
vocabulary_highlights: supporting beam, post and beam structure, mechanicals, essential to scale

speaker: Claire Hughes Johnson
text: The concept is the following, which is when you yank people out of their day-to-day routine, you create space, and also you imprint memory. And so if you say, 'We're going to do a very different thing with your time today or the next two days, we're not going to do our emails, we're not going to do our regular meetings, we are going to sit and work together, we're going to brainstorm,' you're basically activating new parts of their brain.
text_ko: 사람들을 일상에서 잠깐 떼어내면 새로운 공간이 생기고 기억이 남게 돼요. 그래서 '오늘이나 내일은 아주 다른 방식으로 시간을 보낼 거예요. 이메일도 안 하고, 정기 회의도 없고, 함께 앉아서 브레인스토밍을 할 거예요'라고 말하면, 사실 그들의 뇌의 새로운 부분을 활성화시키는 거예요.
text_zh: 这个概念是，当你把人们从日常生活中抽离出来时，你就创造了空间，同时也留下了记忆。因此，如果你说：“今天或接下来的两天我们将以非常不同的方式利用时间，我们不做邮件，不开常规会议，而是一起坐下来合作，进行头脑风暴”，你实际上是在激活他们大脑中的新区域。
text_es: El concepto es el siguiente: cuando sacas a las personas de su rutina diaria, creas un espacio y también dejas una huella en la memoria. Así que si dices: 'Hoy o durante los próximos dos días vamos a hacer algo muy diferente con su tiempo, no vamos a revisar correos electrónicos, no vamos a tener nuestras reuniones habituales, vamos a sentarnos a trabajar juntos, vamos a hacer una lluvia de ideas', estás activando nuevas partes de su cerebro.
context: Lenny asks about the importance of offsite meetings for team cohesion. Claire explains that offsites allow teams to step away from their regular tasks and routines, enabling them to engage creatively and collaboratively. This shift in environment can foster deeper connections and enhance team dynamics, leading to more effective problem-solving and planning.
vocabulary_highlights: yank people out, imprint memory, activate new parts of their brain, brainstorm

speaker: Claire Hughes Johnson
text: I think the main thing is, and Fred Kaufman has this in his book, Conscious Business, this concept of a left-hand column, which is you're in a dialogue with me or you're watching a meeting happen, and you've got a running commentary in your head.
text_ko: 주요한 점은, 프레드 카우프만이 그의 책 'Conscious Business'에서 말한 왼쪽 열(left-hand column) 개념이에요. 이건 저와 대화 중이거나 회의가 진행되는 걸 지켜보면서 머릿속에서 계속 생각이 떠오르는 상황을 말해요.
text_zh: 我认为最重要的是，弗雷德·考夫曼在他的书《意识商业》中提到的这个左侧栏（left-hand column）的概念。它指的是你与我进行对话，或者你在观察一个会议时，脑海中不断有评论在进行。
text_es: Creo que lo principal es, y Fred Kaufman lo menciona en su libro, "Conscious Business", este concepto de la columna izquierda, que se refiere a que estás en un diálogo conmigo o estás observando una reunión, y tienes un comentario interno en tu mente.
context: Lenny asks Claire for advice on how to communicate uncomfortable feedback effectively. Claire refers to a concept from Fred Kaufman's book that involves recognizing the internal commentary we have during conversations. She suggests that transforming this inner dialogue into constructive feedback can facilitate better communication and understanding within teams.
vocabulary_highlights: left-hand column, running commentary, constructive feedback, facilitate better communication

speaker: Claire Hughes Johnson
text: The other thing is, in the book, I talk about this framework that Bezos uses, type one, type two decisions. Is it high impact? Is it irreversible? Is it not? Really evaluate, what kind of decision is this? How hard is it?
text_ko: 또 한 가지는, 책에서 제가 베조스가 사용하는 프레임워크에 대해 이야기하는데, 타입 1, 타입 2 결정에 대한 거예요. 이 결정이 영향력이 큰지, 되돌릴 수 없는지, 아닌지 정말 잘 평가해봐야 해요. 이 결정이 어떤 종류인지, 얼마나 어려운 결정인지 생각해보는 게 중요해요.
text_zh: 另一个要点是，在书中我提到贝索斯使用的这个框架，分为第一类和第二类决策。这些决策是否具有重大影响？是否不可逆转？是否不是？真正评估一下，这是什么类型的决策？难度有多大？
text_es: La otra cosa es que en el libro hablo sobre este marco que utiliza Bezos, decisiones de tipo uno y tipo dos. ¿Es de alto impacto? ¿Es irreversible? ¿O no? Realmente evalúa, ¿qué tipo de decisión es esta? ¿Qué tan difícil es?
context: Lenny asks Claire for insights on decision-making, particularly for product managers who often lack direct authority. Claire mentions a decision-making framework popularized by Jeff Bezos, which categorizes decisions into two types based on their impact and reversibility. She emphasizes the importance of evaluating decisions carefully to streamline the decision-making process and maintain momentum.
vocabulary_highlights: type one, type two decisions, high impact, irreversible, evaluate

speaker: Claire Vo
text: I communicate to my leaders that my expectation is they bring in the clock speed one click faster. If you think something needs to be done this year, it needs to be done this half. If you think it needs to be done this half, it needs to be done this quarter. This quarter, this month. This week, today. End of day, in this meeting.
text_ko: 저는 제 리더들에게 기대하는 바를 전달해요. 시계 속도(clock speed)를 한 단계 더 빠르게 가져와야 한다고요. 만약 올해 안에 뭔가 해야 한다면, 이번 반기 안에 해야 하고, 이번 반기 안에 해야 한다면 이번 분기 안에 해야 해요. 이번 분기, 이번 달, 이번 주, 오늘, 그리고 오늘 회의 끝나기 전에요.
text_zh: 我跟我的领导层说得很清楚，我的要求就是把节奏再提快一档。你觉得今年要完成的事，那就得这半年搞定。你觉得这半年要做完的，那就得这个季度拿下。这个季度的事这个月做，这周的事今天做。今天的事下班前做完，这周的事这次会上就敲定。
text_es: Les comunico a mis líderes que mi expectativa es que aceleren el ritmo un nivel más. Si creen que algo se tiene que hacer este año, se tiene que hacer este semestre. Si creen que se tiene que hacer este semestre, se tiene que hacer este trimestre. Este trimestre, este mes. Esta semana, hoy. Al final del día, en esta misma reunión.
context: Lenny asks Claire about her tactics for maintaining fast pace while keeping high quality in larger companies. Claire explains her specific approach to preventing organizations from defaulting to slower cadences that match their meeting schedules. She describes how she sets explicit expectations with leadership teams to accelerate their natural timelines by one iteration - essentially compressing every deadline to create urgency and momentum throughout the organization.
vocabulary_highlights: bring in the clock speed one click faster, end of day

speaker: Claire Vo
text: I'm using CPTO for short code of running product and engineering design functionally together. There should be no debates over what's best for product or what's best for engineering, what's best for design speed. What is best for the organization?
text_ko: 제품과 엔지니어링·디자인을 기능적으로 함께 운영하는 걸 줄여서 CPTO(Chief Product & Technology Officer)라고 부르고 있어요. 제품에 가장 좋은 것인지, 엔지니어링에 가장 좋은 것인지, 디자인 속도를 우선해야 하는지로 논쟁할 필요는 없어요. 중요한 건 조직에 가장 좋은 게 무엇인지예요.
text_zh: 我用CPTO这个简称来让产品和工程设计功能性地协同工作。不应该争论什么对产品最好，什么对工程最好，什么对设计速度最好。应该问的是：什么对整个组织最好？
text_es: Estoy usando CPTO como código corto para hacer que producto e ingeniería funcionen juntos en el diseño. No debería haber discusiones sobre qué es mejor para producto o qué es mejor para ingeniería, o qué es mejor para la velocidad de diseño. ¿Qué es lo mejor para la organización?
context: Lenny mentions the trend of combining engineering and product roles under one leader. Claire explains her CPTO (Chief Product and Technology Officer) role, where she manages product, engineering, and design as unified functions. She emphasizes that this structure eliminates internal conflicts between departments by focusing all teams on what serves the overall business objectives rather than optimizing for individual functional goals.
vocabulary_highlights: short code of running, functionally together

speaker: Claire Vo
text: I really believe operating in your zone of genius. I really believe in leaning into strengths. And if you are in a position in which you're good at things and you've been giving a lot of responsibility, but you have tremendous growth edges and you're spending more time on the things you need to level up than the things you are exceptional at, I think that's not fair for the organization.
text_ko: 저는 사람들이 자신의 탁월한 영역(zone of genius)에서 일해야 한다고 정말 믿어요. 자신의 강점(strengths)에 더 기대고 활용하는 것도 정말 중요하다고 생각해요. 그런데 만약 당신이 잘하는 일을 맡아 많은 책임을 지고 있는데 성장해야 할 부분(growth edges)이 커서 역량을 끌어올려야 하는 일에 더 많은 시간을 쓰고, 반대로 본인이 탁월한 일에 쏟는 시간이 적다면 그건 조직에 공정하지 않다고 생각해요.
text_zh: 我特别相信要在自己最擅长的领域发挥作用，要发挥自己的优势。如果你现在的职位上，虽然你各方面都还不错，也被委以重任，但是你还有很大的成长空间，而且你把更多时间花在需要提升的地方，而不是你真正出色的地方，我觉得这对公司来说其实不太公平。
text_es: Realmente creo en trabajar desde tu zona de genialidad (zone of genius). Creo mucho en aprovechar las fortalezas. Y si estás en una posición donde eres bueno en ciertas cosas y te han dado mucha responsabilidad, pero tienes áreas enormes de crecimiento y estás invirtiendo más tiempo en las cosas que necesitas mejorar que en las que realmente destacas, creo que eso no es justo para la organización.
context: Lenny asks Claire about avoiding the trap of taking on too much responsibility just because you're good at things. Claire discusses the importance of operating within your zone of genius - the intersection of what you're exceptional at and what brings you joy. She warns against spending too much time on areas where you need significant development rather than leveraging your natural strengths, as this creates inefficiency for both the individual and the organization.
vocabulary_highlights: zone of genius, leaning into strengths, tremendous growth edges

speaker: Claire Vo
text: I try to stay in an empowered space. I know my value. I have no time for imposter syndrome. It's not a constructive thing for me, but I do think knowing that, as I said earlier, the universe is bendable to your will. There are things we can change. I don't think these numbers are not tractable.
text_ko: 저는 주도적인 상태를 유지하려고 해요. 제 가치를 알고 있고, 임포스터 신드롬(imposter syndrome)에 신경 쓸 시간이 없어요. 그건 제게 건설적이지 않아요. 앞서 말했듯이, 우주는 당신의 의지에 따라 굽힐 수 있다고 생각해요. 우리가 바꿀 수 있는 것들이 있어요. 이 수치들이 해결 불가능하다고는 생각하지 않아요.
text_zh: 我尽量让自己保持在一个充满力量的状态。我知道自己的价值。我没时间搞什么冒牌货综合征(imposter syndrome)。这对我来说没什么建设性，但我确实觉得，就像我之前说的，这个世界是可以被你的意志所改变的。有些事情我们是能改变的。我不认为这些数字是搞不定的。
text_es: Trato de mantenerme en un lugar de poder personal. Conozco mi valor. No tengo tiempo para el síndrome del impostor. No me sirve de nada, pero sí creo que, como dije antes, el universo se puede moldear a tu voluntad. Hay cosas que podemos cambiar. No creo que estos números sean imposibles de mover.
context: Lenny asks Claire about her approach to being a woman in tech leadership. Claire shares her philosophy of staying curious about structural and cultural challenges while maintaining an empowered mindset. She explains how she rejects imposter syndrome as unconstructive, given her proven track record, and instead focuses on her ability to influence change. The 'numbers' she references are the statistics she mentioned earlier about low representation of women in tech leadership roles.
vocabulary_highlights: empowered space, universe is bendable to your will, not tractable

speaker: Claire Vo
text: The reason I'm curious about it is I do think it's complicated and I do think you can be successful, but I don't think we're being successful at the rates I would love to see. And I think we're missing a lot of innovation and a lot of economic growth by not having incredible, technical, capable women start companies and lead organizations.
text_ko: 제가 그걸 궁금해하는 이유는 이게 복잡하다고 생각하면서도 성공할 수 있다고 보지만, 제가 바라는 속도만큼 성공하고 있지는 않다고 느끼기 때문이에요. 그리고 뛰어나고 기술적인(technical) 역량을 가진 유능한 여성들이 회사를 창업하고 조직을 이끌지 못해서 많은 혁신과 경제 성장을 놓치고 있다고 생각해요.
text_zh: 我之所以对这个问题感兴趣，是因为我觉得这事儿确实挺复杂的，而且我相信女性是可以成功的，但问题是现在的成功率还远远达不到我希望看到的水平。我觉得正是因为缺少那些技术能力超强的优秀女性来创业、来领导企业，我们错失了太多创新机会，也损失了很多经济增长的潜力。
text_es: La razón por la que me llama tanto la atención es que creo que es un tema complejo y sí se puede tener éxito, pero no creo que estemos teniendo el éxito que me encantaría ver. Y creo que nos estamos perdiendo muchísima innovación y crecimiento económico al no tener mujeres increíbles, técnicamente capaces, creando empresas y liderando organizaciones.
context: Lenny asks Claire why she stays curious about gender challenges in tech rather than just getting frustrated. Claire explains that her curiosity stems from recognizing the complexity of systemic issues while believing change is possible. She frames the underrepresentation of women in tech leadership not just as an individual career issue, but as an economic opportunity cost - the industry loses innovation and growth potential when talented women aren't starting companies or leading technical organizations.
vocabulary_highlights: at the rates I would love to see, economic opportunity cost

speaker: Claire Vo
text: Is it going to eliminate PMs next year? Probably not. Are the skills required going to shift? Yes. Could they shift much faster than we all anticipate? Probably.
text_ko: 내년에 PM(프로덕트 매니저·프로젝트 매니저)들이 사라질까요? 아마 그럴 것 같지는 않아요. 필요한 역량은 바뀔까요? 네, 바뀔 거예요. 우리가 예상하는 것보다 훨씬 더 빨리 바뀔 수도 있을까요? 아마 그럴 가능성이 있어요.
text_zh: 明年会不会直接干掉PM这个岗位？估计不会。但技能要求会变吗？肯定会变。会不会变得比我们预想的还要快？很有可能。
text_es: ¿Va a eliminar por completo a los project managers el próximo año? Probablemente no. ¿Van a cambiar las competencias que se necesitan? Sí. ¿Podrían cambiar mucho más rápido de lo que todos esperamos? Lo más probable.
context: Lenny introduces Claire's AI tool ChatPRD and asks about AI's impact on product management. Claire shares her perspective on how AI will affect product managers' roles. She believes that while PMs won't be completely replaced in the near term, the fundamental skills and ratios between PMs and other roles will change significantly, and this transformation may happen more rapidly than the industry expects.
vocabulary_highlights: shift much faster than we all anticipate

speaker: Crystal Widjaja
speaker_expertise: Product Strategy, Growth Strategy, B2B SaaS
text: I felt like it was a problem that was very solvable. And we ended up renting a stadium to just hire 60,000 drivers in a couple of weeks. So I think looking back, it was certainly a risk. When I got there it was in a house and I realized I've probably made a huge mistake, but we were growing very quickly already, even at that small scale of 4,000 orders per day.
text_ko: 충분히 해결할 수 있는 문제라고 생각했어요. 결국 우리는 몇 주 만에 6만 명의 기사들을 뽑기 위해 경기장까지 빌렸어요. 돌이켜보면 확실히 큰 리스크(risk)였던 것 같아요. 처음 그곳에 갔을 땐 사무실이 집 같아서 ‘아, 큰 실수를 한 건 아닐까’ 싶었는데, 그 작은 규모—하루 4,000건의 주문—에서도 이미 굉장히 빠르게 성장하고 있었어요.
text_zh: 我觉得这个问题完全可以解决。后来我们直接租了个体育场，两周内就招了6万名司机。现在回头看，确实挺冒险的。我到那儿一看，公司就在一个民房里办公，当时心想完蛋了，估计做了个超级错误的决定。不过我们增长得确实很快，哪怕那时候规模还很小，一天也有4000单了。
text_es: Yo sentía que era un problema que se podía resolver perfectamente. Y terminamos rentando un estadio para contratar 60,000 conductores en un par de semanas. Entonces, viéndolo en retrospectiva, definitivamente fue un riesgo. Cuando llegué allí estaba en una casa y me di cuenta de que probablemente había cometido un error enorme, pero ya estábamos creciendo súper rápido, incluso a esa pequeña escala de 4,000 pedidos por día.
context: Crystal is introducing herself and her path to joining Gojek, the ride-hailing company that became Southeast Asia's largest super app. She's explaining how she took a major career risk by cold-emailing Gojek and moving to Indonesia to work for what was then a very early-stage startup. The quote illustrates the unconventional, massive-scale hiring approach they used to rapidly onboard drivers - literally renting a stadium to hire tens of thousands of people at once.
vocabulary_highlights: very solvable, made a huge mistake, at that small scale

speaker: Crystal Widjaja
speaker_expertise: Product Strategy, Growth Strategy, B2B SaaS
text: I literally emailed someone after Googling HR at Gojek and said, 'I'm willing to move to Indonesia, take a bet on me.' And they actually did. So I got extremely lucky. Five years fly by insanely fast. I went through building out the data team from scratch.
text_ko: 실제로 고젝의 인사(HR)를 구글링해보고 누군가에게 이메일을 보냈어요. "인도네시아로 이사할 의향이 있으니 저한테 한 번 기회를 주세요."라고요. 그리고 진짜 그렇게 해주셨어요. 정말 운이 좋았어요. 5년은 순식간에 지나가더라고요. 그동안 데이터 팀(data team)을 완전히 처음부터 만들어봤어요.
text_zh: 我直接谷歌搜了Gojek的HR邮箱，给他们发邮件说："我愿意搬到印尼去，赌我一把吧。" 没想到他们真的同意了，我运气太好了。五年时间眨眼就过去了，我从零开始把数据团队给搭建起来了。
text_es: Literalmente le mandé un email a alguien después de buscar en Google "HR en Gojek" y le dije: "Estoy dispuesto a mudarme a Indonesia, apuesten por mí." Y de verdad lo hicieron. Así que tuve una suerte increíble. Cinco años se pasan volando. Pasé por todo el proceso de armar el equipo de datos desde cero.
context: Lenny asks Crystal about her unusual career path from investment banking to becoming a key growth leader at Gojek. Crystal explains how she made the transition by cold-emailing startups in Southeast Asia, including Gojek, and asking them to take a chance on her despite having no traditional tech background. She describes her rapid career progression once she joined, building multiple teams from the ground up.
vocabulary_highlights: take a bet on me, got extremely lucky, fly by insanely fast, from scratch

speaker: Crystal Widjaja
speaker_expertise: Product Strategy, Growth Strategy, B2B SaaS
text: We would do things as simple as wanting to test a subscription feature, which was just released in Singapore a couple weeks ago. We ended up saying, 'We have this voucher system that we can distribute vouchers in the back end. We obviously know our driver's phone numbers. Why don't we just add them to a WhatsApp group?'
text_ko: 우리는 싱가포르에서 몇 주 전에 막 출시된 구독 기능(subscription feature)을 테스트해 보고 싶다 같은 정말 단순한 일도 했어요. 결국에는 “백엔드(back end)에서 바우처를 배포할 수 있는 바우처 시스템(voucher system)이 있고, 운전자들 전화번호는 당연히 알고 있으니까 그냥 그들을 WhatsApp 그룹(WhatsApp group)에 추가하면 어떨까요?”라고 말했어요.
text_zh: 我们会做一些很简单的事情，比如想测试一个订阅功能，这个功能几周前刚在新加坡上线。最后我们就说，"我们有这个优惠券系统，可以在后台发放优惠券。我们肯定知道司机的手机号码。为什么不直接把他们拉到一个微信群里呢？"
text_es: Hacíamos cosas tan sencillas como querer probar una función de suscripción que acabábamos de lanzar en Singapur hace un par de semanas. Al final dijimos: "Tenemos este sistema de cupones donde podemos distribuir cupones desde el back end. Obviamente conocemos los números de teléfono de nuestros conductores. ¿Por qué no los agregamos simplemente a un grupo de WhatsApp?"
context: Lenny asks Crystal about scrappy growth tactics that Asian startups use which US companies could learn from. Crystal is explaining Gojek's approach of doing things that don't scale to validate ideas quickly. She's describing how they tested a subscription service concept without building any new technology - instead using existing systems like WhatsApp groups and manual backend processes to create a 'Wizard of Oz' experience that mimicked the final product.
vocabulary_highlights: back end, Wizard of Oz experience

speaker: Crystal Widjaja
speaker_expertise: Product Strategy, Growth Strategy, B2B SaaS
text: The only thing better than knowing... If you have data of what your customers are doing, that is the best data you could ever get. And so if you don't have a tested hypothesis, if you can't think of a way to run an experiment, then honestly that idea is pretty useless.
text_ko: 알고 있는 것보다 더 좋은 건 고객들이 실제로 어떤 행동을 하는지에 대한 데이터예요. 그게 사실 얻을 수 있는 가장 좋은 데이터예요. 그래서 검증된 가설(tested hypothesis)이 없다면, 실험을 해볼 방법(run an experiment)이 떠오르지 않으면 솔직히 그 아이디어는 거의 쓸모없어요.
text_zh: 有一个道理大家都懂...如果你能拿到客户行为数据，那绝对是最值钱的数据了。所以说，如果你连个靠谱的假设都没有，连个实验都不知道怎么设计，那说实话，这个想法基本上就是废的。
text_es: Lo único mejor que saber... Si tienes datos de lo que están haciendo tus clientes, esos son los mejores datos que puedes conseguir. Y entonces, si no tienes una hipótesis probada, si no se te ocurre una manera de hacer un experimento, pues la verdad es que esa idea no sirve para nada.
context: Lenny asks whether Crystal advises startups to be more scrappy and do things that don't scale, given that US culture is different from Southeast Asia. Crystal responds by emphasizing the critical importance of getting real customer behavior data rather than just theorizing about what might work. She argues that any product idea that can't be tested experimentally isn't worth pursuing, regardless of how logical it might seem on paper.
vocabulary_highlights: tested hypothesis, pretty useless
topics: Growth & Marketing, Product Management, Decision Making

speaker: Crystal Widjaja
speaker_expertise: Product Strategy, Growth Strategy, B2B SaaS
text: So mathematically speaking, you're going to get the same level of trends, but the precision at which you understand those trends will become more deep if you have more data. But the underlying information that you're getting out of that won't be very different at larger scales.
text_ko: 수학적으로 보면 추세(trends)의 전반적인 수준은 비슷하게 나와요. 다만 데이터가 많아질수록 그 추세를 이해하는 정밀도(precision)는 높아지고, 더 큰 규모(larger scales)에서 얻는 근본적인 정보(underlying information)는 크게 달라지지 않아요.
text_zh: 从数学角度来讲，你得到的趋势程度其实是一样的，但如果数据更多的话，你对这些趋势的理解会更加精准、更深入。不过呢，在更大规模下，你从中获得的核心信息其实不会有太大差别。
text_es: Matemáticamente hablando, vas a obtener el mismo nivel de tendencias, pero la precisión con la que entiendes esas tendencias va a ser mucho más profunda si tienes más datos. Pero la información de fondo que sacas de ahí no va a ser muy diferente a gran escala.
context: Lenny asks how early-stage startups should approach experimentation when they have limited users and data. Crystal gives a counterintuitive response that you can and should run experiments even with very small sample sizes like 30 people. She explains the mathematical principle that while larger samples give you more precision, the fundamental trends and insights you discover will be similar regardless of whether you have 30 users or 300.
vocabulary_highlights: mathematically speaking, level of trends, underlying information, at larger scales

speaker: Crystal Widjaja
speaker_expertise: Product Strategy, Growth Strategy, B2B SaaS
text: So to say, oh, this is the thing, instrumentation is what's wrong, I think it's a very actionable thing. It's probably one of the most solvable problems out there. It just takes some time and mental model shifts to do it well.
text_ko: 그래서 '아, 이게 문제구나 — 계측(instrumentation)에 문제가 있네'라고 하는 건 제 생각에 꽤 실행 가능한 접근이에요. 아마 해결하기 쉬운 문제들 중 하나일 거예요. 다만 제대로 해내려면 시간과 사고 방식 전환(mental model shifts)이 좀 필요해요.
text_zh: 所以说，要找到问题的根源，仪表监控(instrumentation)才是关键，我觉得这个问题其实很好解决。这可能是最容易搞定的问题之一了，只是需要花点时间，转变一下思路就能做好。
text_es: O sea, decir "ah, este es el problema, la instrumentación es lo que está fallando", me parece algo muy accionable. Probablemente sea uno de los problemas más fáciles de resolver que hay. Solo requiere tiempo y cambiar un poco el chip mental para hacerlo bien.
context: Lenny asks Crystal about her popular blog post 'Why Most Analytics Efforts Fail' and what the root causes are. Crystal explains that the main issue is instrumentation - how companies set up their data tracking. She's emphasizing that while many companies struggle with analytics, the problem is actually quite solvable once you understand that the issue isn't the tools or dashboards, but rather how you instrument and structure your data collection from the beginning.
vocabulary_highlights: instrumentation, actionable thing, most solvable problems, mental model shifts

speaker: Crystal Widjaja
speaker_expertise: Product Strategy, Growth Strategy, B2B SaaS
text: Do not treat metric gathering as entertainment. It's not there for you to be like, 'Oh, that's interesting, how novel,' and then not act on it. So real news is information that changes what you do in the real world.
text_ko: 지표 수집(metric gathering)을 오락거리로 다루지 마세요. '오, 흥미롭네, 신기하네' 하고 끝내고 아무 조치도 안 해서는 안 돼요. 진짜 뉴스는 실제로 당신의 행동을 바꾸게 하는 정보예요.
text_zh: 别把收集数据当成娱乐消遣。不是让你看了之后就"哇，挺有意思的，挺新鲜"，然后就没下文了。真正有价值的信息，是那种能让你在实际工作中改变做法的东西。
text_es: No trates la recolección de métricas como entretenimiento. No está ahí para que digas "Ay, qué interesante, qué curioso" y luego no hagas nada al respecto. Así que las noticias de verdad son información que cambia lo que haces en el mundo real.
context: Crystal is explaining why most analytics efforts fail by using an analogy about how people use Twitter. She compares looking at metrics just to see interesting patterns (without taking action) to using Twitter for entertainment rather than actual news. Crystal emphasizes that data should drive decision-making and behavior changes, not just provide interesting observations that teams discuss but never act upon.
vocabulary_highlights: treat metric gathering as entertainment, how novel, real news

speaker: Dalton Caldwell
text: Have you ever seen in NBA basketball or college basketball where they have the coach mic'd up and it shows what they're actually saying in the huddle? You ever listen to what they actually are saying? They're like, "Okay, we need to really focus and get the ball and win this game." If you actually listen to what the greatest, smartest, most successful athletes are talking about, if you listen to what Tiger Woods is saying to his caddy, it all sounds like pretty mundane stuff. It's not like what Tiger Woods is talking about with his caddy is some impossible to decipher jargon.
text_ko: NBA나 대학 농구에서 코치가 마이크 달린(mic'd up) 모습을 본 적 있어요? 허들(huddle)에서 실제로 뭐라고 하는지 들어본 적 있어요? 들어보면 “자, 진짜 집중해서 공 잡고 이겨야 해” 같은 평범한 말뿐이에요. 가장 뛰어나고 똑똑하고 성공한 선수들이 실제로 무슨 얘기를 하는지 들어보면, 타이거 우즈가 캐디(caddy)에게 하는 말도 다 아주 평범해요. 타이거 우즈가 캐디에게 하는 말이 해독 불가능한 전문 용어로 가득한 건 아니에요.
text_zh: 你有没有看过NBA或者大学篮球比赛，教练身上戴着麦克风，能听到他们在暂停时到底跟队员说什么？你仔细听过他们实际在说啥吗？就是那种"好，我们得集中注意力，拿到球权，赢下这场比赛。"如果你真的去听那些最厉害、最聪明、最成功的运动员平时都聊什么，比如听听老虎伍兹跟他球童说什么，听起来都挺平常的。老虎伍兹跟球童的对话并不是什么高深莫测的专业术语。
text_es: ¿Has visto alguna vez en la NBA o en el básquet universitario cuando le ponen micrófono al entrenador y muestran lo que dice realmente en la charla del equipo? ¿Has escuchado lo que dicen en realidad? Es como "Bueno, necesitamos concentrarnos de verdad, conseguir el balón y ganar este partido." Si te pones a escuchar lo que hablan los atletas más exitosos, los más inteligentes, si escuchas lo que Tiger Woods le dice a su caddie, todo suena bastante normal. No es que Tiger Woods esté hablando con su caddie en algún lenguaje técnico imposible de entender.
context: Lenny asks Dalton why founders need to hear simple, pragmatic advice like "sell shit, make money, don't run out of money" when it seems obvious. Dalton explains that even elite performers need constant reminders of fundamentals. He compares startup advice to coaching in professional sports, where the most successful coaches focus on basic principles rather than complex strategies.
vocabulary_highlights: mic'd up, impossible to decipher jargon, pretty mundane stuff

speaker: Dalton Caldwell
text: Usually a successful pivot gets warmer instead of colder from what you're an expert at and somehow builds on what you learned on the prior idea. In the case of Brex, it was they had worked on a FinTech company in Brazil when they were younger, and so I'm like, "You need to work more on the thing all about and not the thing nothing about." And that was what worked for them. A good pivot is like going home. It's warmer, it's closer to something that you're an expert at.
text_ko: 보통 성공적인 피벗(pivot)은 자신이 전문인 영역에서 더 멀어지는 게 아니라 오히려 더 가까워지고, 이전 아이디어에서 배운 걸 어떻게든 이어서 쌓아요. 브렉스(Brex)의 경우엔 어렸을 때 브라질에서 핀테크(FinTech) 회사에서 일한 경험이 있어서, 제가 "완전히 잘 아는 쪽을 더 파고들고, 전혀 모르는 쪽을 억지로 파지 마세요"라고 했어요. 그게 그들에게 통했던 거예요. 좋은 피벗은 집으로 돌아가는 것 같아요. 더 따뜻하고, 자신이 잘 아는 쪽에 더 가깝죠.
text_zh: 通常成功的转型(pivot)不是让你远离自己的专业领域，而是让你更贴近它，而且能够很好地利用你之前项目学到的东西。拿Brex来说吧，他们年轻的时候就在巴西做过金融科技公司，所以我就跟他们说："你们应该做自己懂的东西，而不是完全不懂的东西。"结果这个方向就对了。好的转型就像回家一样，让你感觉更舒服，更贴近你真正擅长的领域。
text_es: Normalmente, cuando haces un pivote exitoso, te acercas más a lo que realmente dominas en lugar de alejarte, y de alguna manera aprovechas lo que aprendiste con la idea anterior. En el caso de Brex, ellos ya habían trabajado en una empresa FinTech en Brasil cuando eran más jóvenes, entonces yo les dije: "Tienen que enfocarse más en lo que sí saben y no en algo de lo que no tienen ni idea." Y eso fue lo que les funcionó. Un buen pivote es como regresar a casa. Es más cómodo, está más cerca de algo en lo que realmente eres experto.
context: Lenny asks Dalton about what makes a good pivot, noting that many founders call him "the king of the pivot." Dalton explains his philosophy that successful pivots move founders closer to their areas of expertise rather than further away. He uses the metaphor that a good pivot is "like going home" - it should feel warmer and more familiar, building on knowledge and experience from previous work.
vocabulary_highlights: gets warmer instead of colder, like going home

speaker: Dalton Caldwell
text: I think when I talked to aspiring founders about this a lot, they're like, "Yeah, yeah, yeah, I talked to customers. We get it. Cool." And I'm like, "Cool. Well, how many customers do you talk to?" And they're like, "Well." And they get really quiet. And so I think this is one of those things like, hey, you should have a healthy diet and exercise every day or whatever, where people know it and that doesn't mean they do it.
text_ko: 이 얘기를 창업 준비하는 사람들한테 자주 해봤는데, 다들 “네네, 고객한테 얘기해봤어요. 알겠어요, 좋아요.” 이렇게 말해요. 그래서 제가 “그럼 몇 명이나 얘기해봤어요?” 하면 다들 “음…” 하고 갑자기 조용해져요. 이건 마치 매일 건강한 식단 먹고 운동하라는 걸 아는 것과 같아요 — 다들 알고는 있지만 그렇다고 실제로 하진 않는 거죠.
text_zh: 我发现跟那些想创业的人聊这个话题的时候，他们都会说"对对对，我们有跟客户聊啊，这个我们懂的。"然后我就问"好啊，那你们具体跟多少客户聊过？"他们就"这个嘛..."然后就不吭声了。我觉得这就像那种"要健康饮食，要天天运动"的道理一样，大家都知道，但知道是一回事，做不做又是另一回事了。
text_es: Cuando hablo con emprendedores que están empezando sobre este tema, me dicen: "Sí, sí, sí, ya hablo con clientes. Ya lo entendemos. Perfecto." Y yo les digo: "Perfecto. Pero ¿con cuántos clientes hablas realmente?" Y se quedan: "Bueno..." Y se callan completamente. Entonces creo que esto es como esas cosas de "oye, deberías comer saludable y hacer ejercicio todos los días", donde la gente lo sabe pero eso no significa que lo haga.
context: Lenny asks Dalton for advice on how to effectively talk to customers, following up on Gustav's advice about the importance of customer conversations. Dalton points out the gap between founders saying they talk to customers and actually doing it consistently. He compares this to health advice - people know they should eat well and exercise, but knowing and doing are different things.
vocabulary_highlights: aspiring founders, get really quiet

speaker: Dalton Caldwell
text: I think growth and growth hacking and doing all this analytics, A/B testing stuff, is a total waste of time for very early startups. And that one of the weird things about having lots of startup advice on the internet, again, this is one of the reasons we started making videos at YC, is a lot of the advice was catered towards later stage companies. The problem was seed stage founders would consume all the later stage advice and get really confused.
text_ko: 아주 초기 스타트업에겐 성장(growth)이나 그로스 해킹(growth hacking), 애널리틱스(analytics)나 A/B 테스트(A/B testing) 같은 것들이 전부 시간 낭비라고 생각해요. 인터넷에 스타트업 조언이 넘쳐나는 것의 이상한 점 하나가—이게 우리가 YC에서 영상 만들기 시작한 이유 중 하나예요—많은 조언이 후기 단계(later stage) 회사들에 맞춰져 있다는 거예요. 문제는 시드 단계(seed stage) 창업자들이 그런 후기 단계 조언들을 다 보고 섞어 읽다가 되게 혼란스러워진다는 거예요.
text_zh: 我觉得对于刚起步的初创公司来说，搞增长、增长黑客(growth hacking)、还有各种数据分析、A/B测试这些东西，完全是浪费时间。网上有太多创业建议，这也是我们YC开始做视频的原因之一，问题是很多建议其实是针对后期公司的。结果种子轮(seed stage)的创始人看了这些后期建议，就搞得一头雾水。
text_es: Yo creo que todo este rollo del crecimiento y el growth hacking y ponerse a hacer análisis, pruebas A/B y esas cosas, es una total pérdida de tiempo para startups que están empezando. Y una de las cosas raras de tener tanto consejo sobre startups en internet —de hecho, esta es una de las razones por las que empezamos a hacer videos en YC— es que muchos consejos estaban enfocados a empresas en etapas más avanzadas. El problema era que los fundadores en etapa semilla se tragaban todos esos consejos de etapas posteriores y se confundían un montón.
context: During the contrarian corner segment, Lenny asks Dalton to share something he believes that most others don't. Dalton argues that growth hacking and complex analytics are counterproductive for very early startups. He explains that much online startup advice is designed for later-stage companies, but early founders mistakenly apply these advanced tactics when they should focus on getting their first customers instead.
vocabulary_highlights: total waste of time, catered towards, get really confused

speaker: Dalton Caldwell
text: I think the advice that he's referencing here is just how important it is to not overdelegate and for the founders to stay close to things, as well as watch out for the trap of hiring super senior people with fancy resumes, really early in a startup. And the folks that are really great at product, the founders that are always deeply in the weeds on product and still care a lot and are still talking to customers, no matter how late stage it gets.
text_ko: 제가 보기엔 그가 여기서 말하는 조언은, 창업자들(founders)이 일을 지나치게 위임하지 말고 회사 일에 직접 가깝게 있어야 한다는 것과, 스타트업 초기(early stage)에 화려한 이력서를 가진 시니어(senior)들을 너무 일찍 뽑는 함정에 빠지지 말라는 거예요. 그리고 진짜 프로덕트(product)를 잘 만드는 사람들은 늘 제품의 디테일에 깊이 관여하고, 여전히 신경을 많이 쓰며 고객(customers)과 계속 대화하는 창업자들인데, 회사가 아무리 후기(late stage)가 돼도 그건 변하지 않는다고 말하는 거예요.
text_zh: 我觉得他这里说的建议就是，别过度授权，创始人要紧盯着各种事情，还有就是要小心一个坑——初创公司太早就招那些简历特别光鲜的高级人才。真正做产品厉害的那些人，那些创始人们，不管公司发展到什么阶段，他们都会深度参与产品细节，依然很在乎，还是会经常和客户聊天。
text_es: Creo que el consejo al que se refiere es lo importante que es no delegar demasiado y que los fundadores se mantengan cerca de las cosas, además de cuidarse de la trampa de contratar gente muy senior con currículums impresionantes muy temprano en una startup. Y la gente que realmente la rompe con producto son los fundadores que siempre están metidos hasta las orejas en los detalles del producto, que siguen comprometidos al máximo y que siguen hablando con clientes, sin importar qué tan avanzada esté la empresa.
context: Lenny mentions that Lenny Bogdonoff asked him to ask Dalton about things product leaders and startups should watch out for. Dalton explains the danger of over-delegating too early and hiring senior executives with impressive backgrounds before the company is ready. He emphasizes that great product founders stay "deeply in the weeds" and maintain direct customer contact regardless of company stage.
vocabulary_highlights: overdelegate, fancy resumes, deeply in the weeds

speaker: Dalton Caldwell
text: I would argue that if we define it as the company had a near death experience where it was going poorly and the founders seriously wondered if it was all going to be over, a hundred percent of the time people go through that where the founder's like, "Yeah, I guess we're done. I guess we should pack it in." And at least you feel that way at some point in your startup journey, man, everyone goes through that.
text_ko: 제 생각엔 회사를 ‘정말 위기를 겪어서 상황이 안 좋았고 창업자(founder)들이 진짜 이게 끝나는 거 아닌가 고민했던’ 상태로 본다면, 거의 백퍼센트로 사람들이 그런 일을 겪어요. 창업자가 “아, 이제 끝인가 보다. 접어야겠다”라고 말하는 순간을 다들 경험하거든요. 적어도 스타트업 여정(startup journey)에서 한 번쯤은 그렇게 느끼게 돼요, 솔직히 모두 다 그래요.
text_zh: 我觉得吧，如果我们把这个定义为公司遇到了生死关头，就是经营得很糟糕，创始人真的在想"是不是要完蛋了"，那百分之百的人都会经历这种时刻，就是创始人会想"算了，我们完了，该收摊了"。至少在创业路上的某个时候你肯定会有这种感觉，哥们儿，每个人都会经历的。
text_es: Yo diría que si lo definimos como que la empresa pasó por una experiencia casi mortal donde todo iba mal y los fundadores se preguntaban en serio si ya se había acabado todo, el cien por ciento de las veces la gente pasa por eso donde el fundador dice "Sí, creo que ya terminamos. Creo que deberíamos tirar la toalla." Y por lo menos te sientes así en algún momento de tu recorrido como startup, hermano, todos pasamos por eso.
context: Lenny asks Dalton how often he sees startups turn around after seemingly hopeless situations, referencing earlier stories about companies like Brex and Retool. Dalton makes the striking claim that 100% of founders go through moments where they seriously consider giving up. He defines this as a "near death experience" where founders genuinely believe their company might be over, emphasizing this is a universal part of the startup journey.
vocabulary_highlights: near death experience, pack it in

speaker: Dan Hockenmaier
text: One lesson I learned the hard way a bunch of times on this is that if you think about running a marketplace, you're basically like a gardener. You have to have a very light touch. If you're building a SaaS business, you're a construction worker, you're building the product and the features and selling it, and it's this very linear thing. For a marketplace, you're like messing with this ecosystem that you don't actually really understand how it works.
text_ko: 제가 이걸 하면서 여러 번 힘들게 배운 한 가지는, 마켓플레이스(marketplace)를 운영한다고 생각하면 사실 정원사 같은 거예요. 아주 살짝만 손대고 있어야 해요. 반면에 SaaS(SaaS) 비즈니스를 만드는 건 건설 노동자 같은 일이라서 제품과 기능을 만들어 팔면 되는, 훨씬 더 단순하고 순차적인 일이에요. 마켓플레이스는 어떻게 돌아가는지 제대로 알기 힘든 생태계(ecosystem)를 이리저리 건드리는 느낌이에요.
text_zh: 我在这方面吃了好多次亏才明白一个道理，做市场平台(marketplace)就像当园丁一样，你得轻拿轻放，不能瞎折腾。如果你做SaaS生意，那你就是个建筑工人，搭产品、加功能、然后卖出去，这套流程很直线。但做市场平台不一样，你其实是在摆弄一个生态系统，而你压根就不太懂这套生态到底是怎么运转的。
text_es: Una lección que aprendí a las malas muchas veces es que si piensas en manejar un marketplace, básicamente eres como un jardinero. Tienes que tener una mano muy suave. Si estás construyendo un negocio SaaS, eres un obrero de la construcción: construyes el producto, las funcionalidades, lo vendes, y es algo muy lineal. Pero con un marketplace, estás jugando con un ecosistema que en realidad no entiendes bien cómo funciona.
context: Lenny asks Dan about what makes marketplaces different from other businesses and how to approach running them. Dan explains that marketplaces are complex ecosystems with many interconnected variables, unlike linear SaaS businesses. He emphasizes that marketplace actions can have delayed effects - something you do today might impact the business two months later in unexpected ways, making it difficult to trace cause and effect.
vocabulary_highlights: learned the hard way, very light touch, messing with this ecosystem, pulling your hair out

speaker: Dan Hockenmaier
text: I think 50% of the value you get from it is simply building the model. It forces you to understand it and then you get this artifact which you can use to understand how to weigh different opportunities or understand the benefit of working on different things. I think importantly it is not a forecasting tool, so it's not going to replace what your finance team is building to project the business.
text_ko: 제 생각에는 그걸로 얻는 가치의 50% 정도는 사실 모델(model)을 만드는 과정 자체에서 나와요. 모델을 만들다 보면 그걸 더 잘 이해하게 되고, 그 결과로 생기는 산출물(artifact)이 기회들 간의 우선순위를 정하거나 다른 일에 투자했을 때의 효과를 가늠하는 데 도움이 돼요. 중요한 건 이게 예측 도구(forecasting tool)는 아니라는 거예요. 그래서 재무팀(finance team)이 사업을 전망(project the business)하려고 만드는 걸 대체하진 못해요.
text_zh: 我觉得这个模型50%的价值就在于搭建的过程本身。它逼着你去真正理解业务，然后你就有了这么个工具，可以用来权衡不同的机会，或者搞清楚做哪些事情更有价值。但有一点很重要，它不是预测工具，所以不会取代财务团队做的那些业务预测模型。
text_es: Creo que el 50% del valor que obtienes viene simplemente de construir el modelo. Te obliga a entender realmente el tema y luego tienes esta herramienta que puedes usar para evaluar diferentes oportunidades o entender qué tan beneficioso es trabajar en distintas cosas. Y algo importante: no es una herramienta de pronósticos, o sea, no va a reemplazar lo que está construyendo tu equipo de finanzas para proyectar el negocio.
context: Lenny asks Dan to explain what a growth model is and why it's useful for businesses. A growth model is an analytical representation of how a business grows, typically built in a spreadsheet. Dan explains that the primary value comes from the process of building the model itself, as it forces you to understand how your business actually works and creates a framework for evaluating different opportunities.
vocabulary_highlights: get this artifact, weigh different opportunities

speaker: Dan Hockenmaier
text: One of the immediate things that you see when you build these is that your growth is much more sensitive to customer retention than you can ever intuit because there's a lot of interaction between having a healthy retained customer base and everything else you care about, which is the rate at which they're referring new customers, generating content, generating contribution margin.
text_ko: 이런 것들을 만들다 보면 바로 보이는 것 중 하나가 성장률이 고객 유지(customer retention)에 훨씬 더 민감하다는 거예요. 직관으로는 결코 가늠할 수 없을 정도예요. 건강한 유지 고객층(retained customer base)이 있느냐에 따라 신규 고객 추천(referring new customers) 비율, 콘텐츠 생성, 기여 마진(contribution margin) 같은 다른 모든 것들이 서로 밀접하게 얽혀 있기 때문이에요.
text_zh: 当你搭建这些系统的时候，马上就能发现一个现象：你的增长对客户留存的敏感度比你想象的要高得多，因为健康的存量客户群和你关心的其他指标之间有很强的联动效应——比如他们的转介绍率、内容产出，还有贡献边际(contribution margin)的产生。
text_es: Una de las primeras cosas que te das cuenta cuando armas estos modelos es que tu crecimiento es muchísimo más sensible a la retención de clientes de lo que te puedes imaginar, porque hay una interacción brutal entre tener una base sólida de clientes que se quedan contigo y todo lo demás que te importa: la velocidad con la que te refieren clientes nuevos, generan contenido, y aportan margen de contribución.
context: Lenny asks Dan about what he's learned from building growth models for various companies. Dan explains that one of the key insights from building growth models is discovering how much more impactful customer retention is compared to other metrics. Retained customers don't just stay longer - they also refer new customers, create content, and generate more profit, creating compounding effects that are hard to predict without modeling.
vocabulary_highlights: much more sensitive to, can ever intuit, contribution margin

speaker: Dan Hockenmaier
text: Very often I think the biggest wins in retention come from inflecting the early user experience. So if you're at three, six, twelve months out, usually a customer has formed a pretty strong opinion about whether or not they like this product and they have a pretty good understanding of it. But in that very first experience, you have a lot of opportunity to teach them about why this is a valuable product and kind of prove to them that it's valuable.
text_ko: 제 생각엔 유지율(retention)에서 가장 큰 성과는 초기 사용자 경험(early user experience)을 잘 설계해서 바꿔놓는 데서 나오는 경우가 많아요. 보통 3, 6, 12개월 시점이면 고객은 이 제품을 좋아하는지 아닌지에 대해 꽤 확고한 판단을 내리고 있고, 제품을 어떻게 쓰는지도 꽤 잘 이해하고 있어요. 그런데 바로 그 첫 경험에서야말로 이 제품이 왜 가치 있는지 알려주고, 실제로 가치가 있다는 걸 보여줄 수 있는 기회가 많아요.
text_zh: 我觉得用户留存最大的突破往往来自于优化早期的用户体验。你想啊，用户用了三个月、六个月、一年之后，他们对这个产品好不好用基本上已经有定论了，对产品也摸得差不多了。但是在最开始那段体验里，你有很多机会去教会他们这个产品到底有什么价值，让他们真正感受到这个产品的价值所在。
text_es: Muchas veces creo que los mayores éxitos en retención vienen de ajustar bien la experiencia inicial del usuario. O sea, si ya llevas tres, seis, doce meses, normalmente el cliente ya se formó una opinión bastante sólida sobre si le gusta el producto o no, y ya lo conoce bastante bien. Pero en esa primera experiencia, ahí tienes muchísima oportunidad de enseñarles por qué este producto es valioso y como que demostrarles que realmente vale la pena.
context: Lenny asks Dan about successful strategies for increasing customer retention. Dan explains that the biggest retention improvements usually come from optimizing the very early user experience rather than trying to save customers who are about to churn. In the first few interactions, customers are still forming opinions about the product's value, making this the most impactful time to demonstrate worth and create positive impressions.
vocabulary_highlights: inflecting the early user experience, formed a pretty strong opinion, prove to them

speaker: Dan Hockenmaier
text: Why is a marketplace a good business? The first thing is it's like a perfect fit for the venture model, which is why everybody's so interested in them, right? They're very hard to get started, super capital intensive to get started, but once they're rolling, they're very hard to stop. You get this kind of compounding defensibility and gains that makes them very hard to stop.
text_ko: 마켓플레이스(marketplace)가 왜 좋은 사업이냐면, 우선 벤처 모델(venture model)에 딱 맞아떨어지기 때문이에요. 그래서 다들 그렇게 관심을 가지는 거고요. 시작하기가 굉장히 어렵고 초기에 자본집약적(capital intensive)이지만, 일단 굴러가기 시작하면 멈추기 힘들어요. 복리처럼 쌓이는 방어력과 이익(compounding defensibility and gains)이 생겨서 경쟁자가 끼어들기 어려워요.
text_zh: 为什么做平台是个好生意？首先，这种模式特别适合风投(venture model)，所以大家都抢着投，对吧？刚开始确实很难搞起来，烧钱也烧得厉害，但是一旦跑起来了，就很难被干掉了。会形成一种滚雪球式的护城河和收益递增，基本上就停不下来了。
text_es: ¿Por qué un marketplace es un buen negocio? Lo primero es que encaja perfecto con el modelo de venture capital, por eso todo el mundo está tan interesado en ellos, ¿no? Son súper difíciles de arrancar, requieren una inversión brutal para empezar, pero una vez que agarran vuelo, son imparables. Consigues esta especie de defensibilidad acumulativa y ganancias que los hace prácticamente imparables.
context: Lenny asks Dan why he's excited about marketplaces and what makes them attractive businesses. Dan explains that marketplaces have unique characteristics that make them ideal for venture capital investment - they require significant upfront investment and are difficult to launch, but once they achieve momentum, they become increasingly defensible through network effects and compounding advantages that make them hard for competitors to stop.
vocabulary_highlights: perfect fit for the venture model, super capital intensive, compounding defensibility

speaker: Dan Hockenmaier
text: I think ultimately demand is the only thing that matters. If you are successful at aggregating the demand in your industry, you will have the winning marketplace. Because if you go to a supplier, a restaurant or an electrician or a driver and say, 'I have this customer for you that I can give to you at a rate that's going to make you money,' they're always going to say yes. And so demand is the currency.
text_ko: 결국 중요한 건 수요(demand)예요. 업계에서 그 수요를 잘 모으는 것(aggregating the demand)에 성공하면 시장을 이기는 마켓플레이스(marketplace)가 돼요. 공급자든 식당이든 전기공이든 운전기사든 가서 '수익이 나는 조건으로 고객을 데려다줄 수 있어요'라고 말하면 누구든 항상 예스라고 해요. 그래서 수요가 곧 통화(currency)인 거예요.
text_zh: 我觉得说到底，还是需求最重要。如果你能把你这个行业的需求都聚集起来，那你的平台就赢定了。因为你去找供应商，不管是餐厅老板、电工师傅还是司机，你跟他们说"我这儿有客户，能给你介绍生意，而且价格你肯定能赚钱"，他们肯定都会答应的。所以说需求就是硬通货。
text_es: Al final del día, creo que la demanda es lo único que realmente importa. Si logras concentrar toda la demanda de tu sector, vas a tener el marketplace ganador. Porque si te acercas a un proveedor, un restaurante, un electricista o un conductor y le dices: "Tengo este cliente para ti que te puedo pasar a una tarifa con la que vas a ganar dinero", siempre te van a decir que sí. Entonces la demanda es la moneda de cambio.
context: Lenny asks Dan whether marketplace founders should focus more on supply or demand acquisition. Dan explains that while both sides matter, demand ultimately determines marketplace success. He argues that if you can aggregate demand in an industry, suppliers will naturally want to join your platform because you're offering them paying customers at profitable rates, making demand the true currency of marketplace power.
vocabulary_highlights: aggregating the demand, demand is the currency

speaker: Dan Hockenmaier
text: I think the core logical error in the argument for unbundling is that they over focus on one type of improvement, which is user experience and they under focus on the things that make scale businesses have better economics. And so to unpack that, if you look at UX, like if you built a LinkedIn just for construction workers or just for architects or just for investment bankers, you could definitely build some set of features that group liked better than the core LinkedIn experience.
text_ko: 저는 언바운들링(unbundling) 주장의 핵심 논리적 오류가 사용자 경험(user experience) 하나에만 너무 집중하고, 규모 있는 비즈니스가 더 나은 경제성을 갖게 하는 요소들은 간과한다는 점이라고 생각해요. 예를 들어, UX를 살펴보면, 만약 건설 노동자나 건축가, 투자 은행가를 위한 LinkedIn을 만든다면, 그 그룹이 기본 LinkedIn 경험보다 더 좋아할 수 있는 기능들을 분명히 만들 수 있을 거예요.
text_zh: 我觉得拆分论证里的核心逻辑问题是，他们太关注一种改进，就是用户体验(user experience)，但对那些让规模化业务经济效益更好的因素关注不够。展开来说，从用户体验(UX)角度看，比如你专门为建筑工人做一个LinkedIn，或者专门为建筑师做一个，或者专门为投资银行家做一个，你肯定能做出一些这个群体比核心LinkedIn体验更喜欢的功能。
text_es: Creo que el error lógico fundamental en el argumento a favor del unbundling es que se enfocan demasiado en un solo tipo de mejora, que es la experiencia del usuario, y le dan muy poca importancia a las cosas que hacen que los negocios de escala tengan mejores números. O sea, para explicarlo mejor, si te fijas en la UX (user experience), digamos que construyes un LinkedIn solo para trabajadores de la construcción, o solo para arquitectos, o solo para banqueros de inversión, definitivamente podrías crear funciones que a ese grupo le gusten más que la experiencia básica de LinkedIn.
context: Lenny asks Dan about the strategy of creating vertical marketplaces by 'unbundling' horizontal ones like eBay or LinkedIn. Dan explains why most unbundling attempts fail - they focus too much on creating better user experiences for specific segments while ignoring the economic advantages that come from scale, such as higher customer lifetime value and stronger network effects that horizontal platforms enjoy.
vocabulary_highlights: core logical error, over focus, under focus, to unpack that

speaker: Dan Shipper
text: I'm going to go with my hottest take, and this is the take that I have the least evidence for. So let's just start with that. I have other more well-reasoned takes to give you, but this is my hottest one, which is I think that AI may be one of the biggest force for reshoring American jobs.
text_ko: 일단 제일 '핫테이크(hottest take)'부터 말할게요. 이건 제가 근거가 제일 약한 주장인데요, 그 얘기부터 시작하죠. 더 합리적이고 근거 있는 분석들도 있지만, 제 가장 강한 주장은 AI가 미국 일자리의 리쇼어링(reshoring)을 이끄는 가장 큰 힘 중 하나가 될 수 있다는 거예요.
text_zh: 我要说一个最大胆的观点，而且这个观点我手头的证据是最少的。咱们就先从这个说起吧。我还有其他更有依据的观点可以跟你分享，但这是我最激进的一个观点——我觉得AI可能会成为让美国工作岗位回流(reshoring)的最大推动力之一。
text_es: Voy a ir con mi opinión más arriesgada, y esta es la que tengo menos evidencia para respaldar. Así que empecemos por ahí. Tengo otras opiniones más fundamentadas que te puedo dar, pero esta es la más atrevida: creo que la IA podría ser una de las fuerzas más grandes para traer de vuelta empleos americanos.
context: Lenny asks Dan what he believes about AI that most people don't believe. Dan shares his most contrarian prediction about AI's impact on employment. While many people worry about AI eliminating jobs, Dan believes AI could actually bring jobs back to America by making expensive services affordable for smaller companies and allowing American workers to serve more customers efficiently using AI tools.
vocabulary_highlights: hottest take, well-reasoned takes, reshoring

speaker: Dan Shipper
text: And what I noticed with him is he was just making a year. He made a year's worth of progress in two months because every time I sat down with him and told him, okay, here's how you tell a story. Here's how you think about a headline. He recorded all of it, put it into a prompt, and he never made the same mistake twice.
text_ko: 제가 그에게서 본 건, 그가 2개월 만에 1년치 성과를 만들어냈다는 거예요. 제가 매번 그와 앉아서 "이렇게 이야기를 풀어야 해, 헤드라인(headline)은 이렇게 생각해"라고 알려주면 그는 전부 녹음해서 프롬프트(prompt)에 넣고 같은 실수를 두 번 다시 하지 않았어요.
text_zh: 我发现他的进步特别快，两个月就走完了别人一年的路。因为每次我跟他坐下来聊，告诉他该怎么讲故事，怎么想标题，他都会录下来，整理成提示词(prompt)，同样的错误绝对不犯第二次。
text_es: Y lo que noté con él es que estaba avanzando a toda velocidad. Hizo el progreso de un año completo en solo dos meses porque cada vez que me sentaba con él y le decía, "mira, así es como cuentas una historia, así es como piensas en un titular", él lo grababa todo, lo metía en un prompt, y nunca volvía a cometer el mismo error.
context: Dan is explaining why he disagrees with headlines saying AI will eliminate entry-level jobs. He describes working with a young employee named Alex who accelerated his learning dramatically by using AI. Instead of traditional mentoring where people repeat mistakes, this employee recorded all feedback, converted it into prompts, and used AI to avoid making the same errors repeatedly.
vocabulary_highlights: a year's worth of progress, never made the same mistake twice

speaker: Dan Shipper
text: We have a head of AI operations. I sit with her once a week. And every time I'm doing something repetitively, we put it in a to-do list. And she's just constantly building prompts and building workflows that I and everyone else on the team are just automating as much as possible.
text_ko: 저희 팀에는 AI 운영 책임자(head of AI operations)가 있어요. 저는 매주 한 번 그녀와 같이 앉아서 얘기해요. 같은 일을 반복하면 그걸 바로 할 일 목록(to-do list)에 올리고요. 그녀는 계속해서 프롬프트(prompts)와 워크플로(workflows)를 만들어서 저랑 팀원들 모두가 가능한 한 많이 자동화하고 있어요.
text_zh: 我们有个AI运营负责人。我每周都跟她坐下来聊一次。每次我发现自己在重复做什么事情，我们就把它加到待办清单里。然后她就不停地在那儿搭建提示词(prompts)和工作流程(workflows)，让我和团队其他人尽可能多地实现自动化。
text_es: Tenemos una jefa de operaciones de IA. Me reúno con ella una vez por semana. Y cada vez que estoy haciendo algo repetitivo, lo apuntamos en una lista de pendientes. Y ella está constantemente creando prompts y armando flujos de trabajo para que yo y todo el equipo podamos automatizar lo más posible.
context: Lenny asks Dan about how his 15-person team operates so efficiently across multiple products and a consulting business. Dan explains their key innovation of having a dedicated AI operations person whose job is to identify repetitive tasks across the organization and build AI automations for them, allowing everyone to focus on higher-value work instead of manual processes.
vocabulary_highlights: head of AI operations, building workflows, automating as much as possible

speaker: Dan Shipper
text: One of the things that we do that I think is really cool, and they basically invented this, I had nothing to do with this, is they invented the idea of compounding engineering. So basically, for every unit of work, you should make the next unit of work easier to do.
text_ko: 우리가 하는 것 중 하나인데 진짜 멋진 거예요. 그리고 이걸 사실상 처음 고안한 사람들이고 저는 전혀 관여하지 않았어요. '컴파운딩 엔지니어링(compounding engineering)'이라는 아이디어인데, 쉽게 말하면 한 단위의 작업을 할 때마다 다음 작업이 더 쉬워지게 만들어야 한다는 거예요.
text_zh: 我们做的一件我觉得特别酷的事情，这基本上是他们发明的，跟我没什么关系，就是他们发明了复合工程(compounding engineering)这个概念。简单来说就是，每做一个单位的工作，都要让下一个单位的工作变得更容易做。
text_es: Una de las cosas que hacemos que me parece súper genial, y que básicamente ellos inventaron - yo no tuve nada que ver con esto - es que inventaron el concepto de ingeniería compuesta (compounding engineering). Entonces básicamente, por cada unidad de trabajo que hagas, deberías hacer que la siguiente unidad de trabajo sea más fácil de realizar.
context: Dan is describing innovative engineering practices his team uses. His engineers Kieran and Nityesh developed this concept where instead of just completing tasks, they build tools and prompts that make similar future tasks easier. This creates a compound effect where the team becomes more efficient over time rather than just maintaining the same productivity level.
vocabulary_highlights: compounding engineering, unit of work

speaker: Dan Shipper
text: I think the number one predictor is, does the CEO use ChatGPT, or insert your own chatbot. If the CEO is in it all the time, being like, this is the coolest thing, everybody else is going to start doing it. If the CEO is like, I don't know, this is for someone else, no one else is going to be able to lead that charge.
text_ko: 제일 큰 예측 요소는 최고경영자(CEO)가 ChatGPT(챗GPT)나 자체 챗봇(chatbot)을 실제로 쓰느냐예요. CEO가 항상 쓰면서 “이거 진짜 멋지다”라고 하면 다른 사람들도 곧 따라 하기 시작해요. 반대로 CEO가 “글쎄, 이건 다른 사람들 일이야”라며 거리를 두면 아무도 그 변화를 주도하지 못해요.
text_zh: 我觉得最重要的预测指标就是，CEO自己用不用ChatGPT，或者别的什么聊天机器人(chatbot)。如果CEO天天在那儿摆弄这个，说这玩意儿太酷了，那下面的人肯定都会跟着用起来。但如果CEO的态度是，我也不懂，这是别人的事儿，那公司里就不会有人能推动这个事儿了。
text_es: Creo que el factor más determinante es si el CEO usa ChatGPT, o ponle el chatbot que quieras. Si el CEO está metido en eso todo el tiempo, diciendo "esto es lo más genial que hay", entonces todos los demás van a empezar a usarlo. Pero si el CEO dice "no sé, esto es para otros", nadie más va a poder liderar ese cambio.
context: Lenny asks what separates companies that successfully adopt AI from those that don't, based on Dan's consulting experience with large organizations. Dan shares his most reliable predictor for AI adoption success. He explains that CEO engagement with AI tools directly determines whether the entire organization will embrace these technologies, because leaders need both excitement and realistic expectations that only come from hands-on experience.
vocabulary_highlights: number one predictor, lead that charge

speaker: Dan Shipper
text: And what I noticed using, at the time, like GPT-3 or maybe GPT-4, was that I was spending a lot of time, for example, thinking about, how do I communicate the problem? How do I gather the right information for the problem? How do I put it in the right way so that the model that I'm working with gets it?
text_ko: 당시에 GPT-3이나 어쩌면 GPT-4(GPT-3, GPT-4)를 쓰면서 제가 깨달은 건, 예컨대 문제를 어떻게 전달할지, 문제에 맞는 정보를 어떻게 모을지, 그리고 함께 작업하는 모델이 제대로 이해하도록 어떻게 표현할지에 많은 시간을 쏟고 있다는 거였어요.
text_zh: 我当时用GPT-3或者GPT-4的时候发现，我花了特别多时间在想，怎么把问题说清楚？怎么收集对的信息？怎么用合适的方式表达，让模型能真正理解我想要什么？
text_es: Y lo que me di cuenta usando, en ese momento, como GPT-3 o tal vez GPT-4, era que estaba gastando muchísimo tiempo, por ejemplo, pensando en, ¿cómo le comunico el problema? ¿Cómo recopilo la información correcta para el problema? ¿Cómo lo planteo de la manera adecuada para que el modelo con el que estoy trabajando lo entienda?
context: Dan explains his "allocation economy" thesis - his prediction that we're moving from a knowledge economy to one where management skills become more valuable. He describes how using AI tools early on made him realize he was spending time on tasks that mirror traditional management: communicating problems clearly, gathering information, providing feedback, and coordinating between different capabilities.
vocabulary_highlights: communicate the problem, gather the right information, gets it

speaker: Daniel Lereya
speaker_expertise: Product Strategy, Team Building, Growth Strategy
text: Some of our competitors did something that we can only imagine. We said, 'Okay. We need to treat it differently.' We received a gift from our competitors. They showed us that it's possible. Use your competition, know it, and take it, and set ambitious goals, and believe in yourself, and you can do amazing things.
text_ko: 우리 경쟁자들 중 몇몇은 우리가 상상만 하던 일을 실제로 해냈어요. 그래서 우리는 '이건 다르게 해야 해요'라고 했어요. 사실 그들은 우리에게 선물을 준 셈이에요 — 가능하다는 걸 보여줬거든요. 경쟁을 잘 활용하고, 그걸 받아들이며 야심 찬 목표를 세우고 자신을 믿으면 놀라운 일들을 해낼 수 있어요.
text_zh: 我们的竞争对手做了一些我们之前想都不敢想的事情。我们当时就想，"行，我们得换个思路了。" 竞争对手其实给了我们一个礼物，他们让我们看到了什么叫可能。你要利用你的竞争对手，了解他们，学习他们，然后给自己定个高目标，相信自己，你就能做出很牛的事情来。
text_es: Algunos de nuestros competidores hicieron algo que nosotros ni nos imaginábamos. Dijimos, 'Bueno. Tenemos que enfocar esto de otra manera.' Nuestros competidores nos dieron un regalo. Nos demostraron que sí se puede. Aprovecha tu competencia, conócela bien, tómala como referencia, ponte metas ambiciosas, cree en ti mismo, y puedes lograr cosas increíbles.
context: Lenny asks Daniel about a moment when he realized their competitors were shipping much faster than Monday.com. Daniel explains how they discovered a competitor had launched 30 new column types while Monday had only 5 (with each taking 4 months to develop). Instead of being discouraged, Daniel describes how they viewed this competitive challenge as validation that rapid development was possible, which motivated them to completely rethink their approach and set the ambitious goal of building 25 columns in one month.
vocabulary_highlights: we can only imagine, received a gift, set ambitious goals
topics: Product Management, Strategy & Planning, Leadership & Management

speaker: Daniel Lereya
speaker_expertise: Product Strategy, Team Building, Growth Strategy
text: We really have an approach of very radical transparency about everything. Before we went public, we actually shared every bit of information with our employees. Instead of demoralizing people, I think that this is something that gives them a sense of deep partnership. We really want everyone's brains in the challenge, and not just one centralized brain and a lot of working hands.
text_ko: 저희는 사실 모든 것에 대해 굉장히 급진적 투명성(radical transparency)을 지향해요. 상장(going public)하기 전에 직원들에게 모든 정보를 다 공유했어요. 그게 사람들 사기를 꺾는 대신 오히려 깊은 동반자 의식을 주는 것 같아요. 우리는 정말 모든 사람이 이 과제에 머리를 맞대길 바라요. 한 사람의 중앙화된 두뇌(centralized brain)와 일만 하는 많은 손들만 있는 구조가 아니라요.
text_zh: 我们的做法就是对所有事情都超级透明。在上市之前，我们其实把所有信息都跟员工分享了。这不但没有打击大家的积极性，我觉得反而让他们有一种深度合作的感觉。我们真的希望每个人都能动脑子参与到挑战中来，而不是只有一个大脑在中央指挥，其他人就是干活的。
text_es: Tenemos un enfoque de transparencia radical en todo, de verdad. Antes de salir a bolsa, compartíamos absolutamente toda la información con nuestros empleados. En lugar de desmoralizar a la gente, creo que esto les da una sensación de ser socios de verdad. Queremos que todos pongan el cerebro en los desafíos, no solo un cerebro centralizado y un montón de manos trabajando.
context: Lenny asks Daniel about the most counterintuitive thing he's learned building Monday.com. Daniel explains their philosophy of radical transparency, where they share all company metrics and financial data with employees, even displaying dashboards publicly in their office. He describes how this approach creates partnership rather than demoralization, engaging everyone's intellectual capacity rather than treating them as just executors of centralized decisions.
vocabulary_highlights: radical transparency, sense of deep partnership, centralized brain

speaker: Daniel Lereya
speaker_expertise: Product Strategy, Team Building, Growth Strategy
text: A great PM basically for me is someone that is relentless until he gets this impact, until he validates that this impact is in place. In some cases, doing the biggest impact is not developing another feature, it's about making the current value more accessible.
text_ko: 제가 생각하는 훌륭한 프로덕트 매니저(PM)는 임팩트(impact)가 나올 때까지, 그 임팩트가 실제로 자리 잡았는지 검증될 때까지 끝까지 포기하지 않고 밀어붙이는 사람이에요. 어떤 경우에는 가장 큰 임팩트를 내는 게 새 기능을 만드는 게 아니라 현재의 가치(value)를 더 쉽게 이용할 수 있게 만드는 일이에요.
text_zh: 在我看来，优秀的产品经理(PM)就是那种不达目的不罢休的人，一定要看到实际效果，确认影响力真的落地了才算完。很多时候，要想产生最大影响力，不是去开发新功能，而是让现有的价值更容易被用户感知和使用。
text_es: Un gran PM para mí es básicamente alguien que no para hasta conseguir ese impacto, hasta validar que ese impacto realmente está ahí. En algunos casos, lograr el mayor impacto no es desarrollar otra funcionalidad más, sino hacer que el valor actual sea más accesible.
context: Lenny asks Daniel about focusing on impact rather than just building features. Daniel explains how Monday.com shifted from measuring teams by output to measuring by customer impact. He defines what makes a great product manager - someone who persistently pursues measurable impact rather than just shipping features. Daniel emphasizes that sometimes the highest impact comes from improving accessibility of existing features rather than building new ones.
vocabulary_highlights: relentless until, making the current value more accessible

speaker: Daniel Lereya
speaker_expertise: Product Strategy, Team Building, Growth Strategy
text: I think there are fake speed, which means, trying to do the same work by skipping stages or not doing the high quality that you want, but there's the real speed, and speed of organizations, and speed of execution. Many times, it's about doing things right. It's about understanding, A, what is going to move the needle? And work only on that.
text_ko: 사실 '가짜 속도(fake speed)'가 있어요. 단계들을 건너뛰거나 원하는 수준의 품질을 포기하면서 같은 일을 빨리 끝내려는 거예요. 반면에 '진짜 속도(real speed)'가 있고, 조직의 속도(speed of organizations), 실행 속도(speed of execution)가 있어요. 많은 경우에는 일을 빨리 하는 것보다 일을 제대로 하는 게 중요해요. 무엇이 진짜 성과를 움직일지(move the needle)를 이해하고 그 일에만 집중해야 해요.
text_zh: 我觉得有一种假的速度，就是想要跳过某些阶段或者不按你想要的高质量标准去做，但真正的速度是组织的速度和执行的速度。很多时候，关键是要把事情做对。首先要搞清楚什么事情真正能起到关键作用，然后就专门做那些事。
text_es: Creo que existe la velocidad falsa, o sea, tratar de hacer el mismo trabajo saltándote etapas o sin hacer el trabajo de calidad que realmente quieres, pero también está la velocidad real, la velocidad de las organizaciones y la velocidad de ejecución. Muchas veces se trata de hacer las cosas bien. Se trata de entender, primero, ¿qué es lo que realmente va a mover la aguja (move the needle)? Y trabajar solamente en eso.
context: Lenny discusses the power of setting ambitious goals and how people might interpret this as working harder or longer hours. Daniel clarifies the difference between false speed (cutting corners or working more hours) versus real organizational speed. He explains that true speed comes from working smarter by focusing only on what will actually move key metrics and thinking differently about problem-solving approaches rather than just increasing effort.
vocabulary_highlights: fake speed, move the needle, speed of organizations
topics: Product Management, Strategy & Planning, Leadership & Management

speaker: Daniel Lereya
speaker_expertise: Product Strategy, Team Building, Growth Strategy
text: Don't be afraid again to let go of things that you think are superpowers. Many times your superpowers that brought you to this point and made you successful, many times you think that if you let it go you won't be successful and it's frightening. But, I really feel that you need to constantly evaluate what your current role is actually, is actually what is the role?
text_ko: 자신을 슈퍼파워(superpowers)라고 생각하는 것들을 더 이상 놓는 걸 두려워하지 마세요. 지금까지 당신을 여기까지 데려오고 성공하게 만든 그런 능력들이 있어서, 그것을 버리면 앞으로 성공하지 못할까 봐 겁나는 경우가 많아요. 하지만 저는 지금 자신의 역할이 실제로 무엇인지 계속해서 점검하고 재평가해야 한다고 정말 느껴요.
text_zh: 别再害怕放掉那些你觉得是你超能力的东西。很多时候，那些让你走到今天、让你成功的超能力，你总觉得一旦放手就不会成功了，这挺吓人的。但是我真的觉得，你得不断地问问自己，你现在的角色到底是什么，真正的角色是什么？
text_es: No tengas miedo de soltar esas cosas que crees que son tus superpoderes. Muchas veces esos superpoderes que te trajeron hasta aquí y te hicieron exitoso, muchas veces piensas que si los sueltas ya no vas a ser exitoso y da miedo. Pero, realmente siento que tienes que estar constantemente evaluando cuál es tu rol actual en realidad, o sea, ¿cuál es realmente el rol?
context: Lenny asks Daniel what he wishes he'd known before stepping into his current leadership role. Daniel reflects on how his role has changed dozens of times as Monday.com scaled from 4 million to 1 billion in ARR and from 40 to 2,500 employees.
