He explains that skills that made him successful at earlier stages (like knowing every detail) sometimes became counterproductive as the company grew, and leaders must be willing to abandon their former strengths when the role demands different capabilities.
vocabulary_highlights: let go of things, superpowers, constantly evaluate

speaker: Daniel Lereya
speaker_expertise: Product Strategy, Team Building, Growth Strategy
text: I really love using the deadline trap and it makes you focused, it makes you sharper in thinking. And, we just had a recent example with the offering I was telling you about of enterprise work management, managing project at scale. And this is an enterprise product. So you have all the reasons in the world to say, 'No, I can't release it, yet. I need more time.'
text_ko: 저는 데드라인 트랩(deadline trap)을 정말 좋아해요. 그게 집중하게 만들고 사고를 더 날카롭게 해줘요. 그리고 전에 말씀드렸던 엔터프라이즈 업무 관리(enterprise work management), 대규모 프로젝트 관리(managing projects at scale) 관련 오퍼링(offering)에서 최근 그런 사례가 있었어요. 이건 기업용 제품(enterprise product)이니까 "아직 출시할 수 없어요. 시간이 더 필요해요."라고 말할 만한 이유가 충분히 있죠.
text_zh: 我特别喜欢用截止日期来逼自己，这样能让你更专注，思路也更敏锐。我们最近就有个例子，就是我刚跟你说的那个企业工作管理的产品，做大规模项目管理的。这是个企业级产品，所以你有一万个理由说"不行，还不能发布，我还需要更多时间。"
text_es: Me encanta usar la trampa del deadline y te hace enfocar, te agudiza el pensamiento. Y justo tuvimos un ejemplo reciente con la oferta de la que te hablaba de gestión empresarial de trabajo, manejar proyectos a gran escala. Y este es un producto enterprise. Entonces tienes todas las razones del mundo para decir: "No, no lo puedo lanzar todavía. Necesito más tiempo."
context: Lenny asks about Daniel's philosophy of time-boxing projects versus working until they're 'perfect.' Daniel explains their approach of setting artificial deadlines (which he calls 'traps') to force teams to focus on core value rather than invented requirements. He shares an example of releasing an alpha version of their enterprise product that customers said was 'premature,' but this gave them precise feedback about what was actually needed rather than theoretical concerns.
vocabulary_highlights: deadline trap, makes you sharper, all the reasons in the world
topics: Product Management, Strategy & Planning, Decision Making

speaker: David Placek
text: When we presented Sonos, which has many qualities to it, it was rejected because it doesn't have enough emotion to it. It's not entertainment-like. And we argued about that because I said, "This is outside looking in, but I don't see you as an entertainment company. You make speakers that allow for the flow of entertainment through these things. And Sonos is about sound."
text_ko: 소노스를 소개했을 때, 여러 좋은 점이 있음에도 불구하고 감정이 부족하다는 이유로 거절당했어요. 너무 오락적인 느낌이 없다는 거죠. 그래서 우리는 이 부분에 대해 논쟁을 했어요. 제가 "이건 외부에서 본 시각이지만, 저는 당신들이 오락 회사라고 생각하지 않아요. 당신들은 오락이 흐를 수 있도록 도와주는 스피커를 만드는 거고, 소노스는 소리에 관한 거예요."라고 말했거든요.
text_zh: 当我们提Sonos这个方案的时候，虽然它各方面都不错，但被否了，说是缺乏情感元素，不够娱乐化。我们就这个争论了一番，我说："这可能是局外人的看法，但我觉得你们本来就不是娱乐公司啊。你们做的是音响，让娱乐内容能够通过这些设备传播出来。而Sonos讲的就是声音本身。"
text_es: Cuando presentamos Sonos, que tiene muchas cualidades, lo rechazaron porque dijeron que no tenía suficiente emoción. Que no era lo suficientemente entretenido. Y discutimos sobre eso porque yo les dije: "Mira, esto es desde afuera mirando hacia adentro, pero yo no los veo como una empresa de entretenimiento. Ustedes fabrican bocinas que permiten que el entretenimiento fluya a través de estos aparatos. Y Sonos se trata del sonido."
context: Lenny asks David for a story about a name he had to fight hard for that the client initially hated. David shares the story of Sonos, where the founders were stuck on wanting a brand name that positioned them in the entertainment business. When Lexicon presented Sonos, it was rejected for not being entertainment-like enough. David had to push back and help them see they weren't an entertainment company, but rather a company that enables the flow of entertainment through their speakers.
vocabulary_highlights: outside looking in, allow for the flow of

speaker: David Placek
text: Most clients, and I can understand this, they come to a naming project absolutely believing, with full confidence, that they're going to know it when they see it. And the truth is, it almost never happens. You're not going to know when you see it. And part of our job here is to help people to give the confidence that going bolder, and bigger, and being uncomfortable.
text_ko: 대부분의 클라이언트들은—저도 이해해요—네이밍 프로젝트(naming project)에 오면 ‘딱 보면 알 거야’라고 완전히 확신하고 오세요. 근데 사실 그런 경우는 거의 없어요. 보자마자 알게 되지는 않아요. 그래서 저희 역할 중 하나는 사람들이 더 대담해지고, 더 크게 생각해보고, 불편함을 감수해도 된다는 자신감을 갖게 도와주는 거예요.
text_zh: 大部分客户，我能理解他们的想法，一开始做命名项目的时候都特别有信心，觉得好名字一看就知道，一眼就能认出来。但实际情况是，这种事儿几乎不会发生。你看到的时候不会马上就知道这就是对的。我们工作的一部分就是帮客户建立信心，让他们敢于走得更大胆一些，格局更大一些，哪怕会感到不太舒服。
text_es: La mayoría de los clientes, y los entiendo perfectamente, llegan a un proyecto de naming totalmente convencidos de que van a saber cuál es el nombre perfecto en cuanto lo vean. Pero la realidad es que casi nunca pasa así. No vas a tener esa revelación cuando lo veas. Y parte de nuestro trabajo aquí es ayudar a la gente a tener la confianza para atreverse más, pensar en grande, y sentirse cómodos con lo incómodo.
context: Lenny asks how often clients reject names initially and David explains this happens frequently. David discusses a fundamental misconception that clients have - they believe they'll immediately recognize the right name when they see it. However, after completing 4,000 projects, David has learned this almost never happens. He explains that clients naturally seek comfort, but great names require boldness and discomfort.
vocabulary_highlights: going bolder, being uncomfortable

speaker: David Placek
text: You don't want to make a statement here. You want to start a story. And Azure is going to behave differently in the marketplace than Cloud Pro, which is I think one of the names that we presented to them on the other site at their request. Your brand name, whether it's a product name or a company name, nothing's going to be used more often or for longer than that name.
text_ko: 여기서는 선언을 하려는 게 아니고, 이야기를 시작하려는 거예요. 그리고 애저(Azure)는 마켓플레이스(marketplace)에서 클라우드 프로(Cloud Pro)와는 다르게 행동할 거예요 — 클라우드 프로는 제가 알기로 그들이 요청해서 우리가 다른 사이트에 제안했던 이름들 중 하나예요. 브랜드명(brand name)은 제품명(product name)이든 회사명(company name)이든, 그 이름보다 더 자주 또는 더 오래 쓰일 건 없어요.
text_zh: 你在这里不是要做个声明，而是要开启一个故事。Azure在市场上的表现会跟Cloud Pro不一样，Cloud Pro是我们之前应他们要求在另一个项目里提出的名字之一。你的品牌名，不管是产品名还是公司名，没有什么比这个名字用得更频繁、用得更久的了。
text_es: No queremos hacer una declaración aquí. Queremos empezar a contar una historia. Y Azure va a comportarse de manera diferente en el mercado que Cloud Pro, que creo que fue uno de los nombres que les presentamos en el otro sitio cuando nos lo pidieron. El nombre de tu marca, ya sea el nombre de un producto o de la empresa, no hay nada que se vaya a usar más seguido o por más tiempo que ese nombre.
context: David is explaining the importance of choosing the right name using Microsoft's Azure as an example. When Microsoft came to them, they wanted a name starting or ending with 'cloud' for their cloud service. David argued this would put them in an 'ocean of other cloud services' and suggested Azure instead. He emphasizes that names should start stories rather than make statements, and that brand names have exceptional longevity compared to other business elements.
vocabulary_highlights: start a story, behave differently in the marketplace, on the other site

speaker: David Placek
text: The first element is humans do like to be comfortable. And one of the mechanisms of comfort is if something's been successful before, then I feel like I can approve it or select it. This is why movies like Harry Potter or even novels like Jack London's Call of the Wild get rejected so many times. We really do have to help people think about, "It's not about the past. You're actually creating the future."
text_ko: 첫째, 사람들은 편안함을 좋아해요. 편안함을 주는 한 가지 메커니즘은 이전에 성공한 것이라면 ‘검증됐으니까 괜찮겠지’ 하고 선택하거나 승인하기 쉬워진다는 거예요. 그래서 해리 포터(Harry Potter) 같은 영화나 잭 런던의 『야성의 부름』(Call of the Wild) 같은 소설이 여러 번 거절당하기도 해요. 우리는 사람들한테 “과거가 중요한 게 아니라, 당신이 실제로 미래를 만들어가고 있다”라고 생각하게 도와줘야 해요.
text_zh: 第一点就是人天生喜欢待在舒适圈里。而舒适感的一个表现就是，如果某个东西以前成功过，我就觉得可以放心批准或者选择它。这就是为什么像《哈利·波特》这样的电影，甚至像杰克·伦敦的《野性的呼唤》这样的小说，都被拒绝过无数次。我们真的需要帮助大家转变思维："这不是看过去怎么样，你们其实是在创造未来。"
text_es: El primer elemento es que a la gente le gusta estar en su zona de confort. Y uno de los mecanismos de esa comodidad es pensar "si algo ya funcionó antes, entonces me siento seguro aprobándolo o eligiéndolo." Por eso es que películas como Harry Potter o incluso novelas como La Llamada de la Selva de Jack London las rechazaron tantas veces. Realmente tenemos que ayudar a la gente a pensar diferente: "No se trata del pasado. En realidad estás creando el futuro."
context: Lenny asks why clients almost never immediately recognize a great name when they see it. David explains the psychology behind this phenomenon - humans naturally seek comfort and prefer things that have been successful before. He uses examples like Harry Potter being rejected 16-18 times and Jack London's Call of the Wild being rejected even more to illustrate how innovative ideas often face initial resistance because they're unfamiliar.
vocabulary_highlights: mechanisms of comfort, creating the future

speaker: David Placek
text: We look for polarization. We look for tension in a team arguing about these things. Polarization is a sign of strength in the word. And when we tell that story, people say, "You're right. There is... I mean, we are arguing about this, and there is an intensity with the name." And that's what you want.
text_ko: 저희는 양극화(polarization)를 찾아요. 팀이 이런 주제로 논쟁할 때 생기는 긴장감(tension)을 원해요. 양극화는 힘이 있다는 신호예요. 그 얘기를 하면 사람들은 “맞아요. 그러니까… 우리가 이걸 두고 실제로 논쟁하고 있고, 그 이름에도 강한 기운이 있어요”라고 말해요. 그게 바로 원하시는 거예요.
text_zh: 我们就是要找那种两极化的感觉，要找团队内部为这些事情争论时产生的那种张力。两极化其实是个好兆头，说明这个词有力量。当我们跟人讲这个故事的时候，他们会说："对啊，确实是这样...我是说，我们确实在为这个争论，而且提到这个名字的时候确实有种强烈的感觉。"这就是你想要的效果。
text_es: Buscamos polarización. Buscamos tensión en el equipo cuando discuten sobre estas cosas. La polarización es señal de que la palabra tiene fuerza. Y cuando contamos esa historia, la gente dice: "Tienen razón. Es cierto... o sea, sí estamos discutiendo sobre esto, y hay una intensidad con el nombre." Y eso es justo lo que quieres.
context: This quote relates to David's philosophy about recognizing strong names. Earlier in the conversation, Lenny mentioned David's quote about teams being comfortable with names, and David explains that they actually look for the opposite - polarization and tension within teams. He shares that Andy Grove taught him this principle during the Pentium naming process, where Grove recognized that polarization indicated energy and strength in a name choice.
vocabulary_highlights: look for polarization, sign of strength

speaker: David Placek
text: There's a lot of overevaluation in our industry. We survive as humans because we figure out what's wrong with this picture. If I want to cross the street, is it safe to cross the street? You have to counter that. You have to say, "Let's just suspend judgment for a while. And let's do an exercise here where we take these 10 names that we think might work and what are we going to do with it."
text_ko: 우리 업계에는 과대평가(overevaluation)가 많아요. 사람이 살아남은 건 상황에서 뭔가 잘못된 점을 찾아내는 능력 덕분이에요. 예를 들어 길을 건너려면 안전한지 확인하잖아요? 그 본능만 믿을 수는 없어요. 그걸 상쇄하려고 '잠시 판단을 보류(suspend judgment)하고, 여기서 연습(exercise) 하나 해볼게요. 우리가 통할 것 같다고 생각하는 10개의 이름을 골라서 그걸로 뭘 해볼지 정해보자'고 말해야 해요.
text_zh: 咱们这个行业啊，估值虚高的情况太多了。咱们人类之所以能生存下来，就是因为会发现问题所在。就像我要过马路，得先看看安全不安全对吧？所以你得反过来想。你得说："咱先别急着下结论，做个练习吧。拿这10个我们觉得可能行的公司名单，看看咱们到底要怎么处理。"
text_es: En nuestra industria hay mucha sobrevaloración. Como seres humanos sobrevivimos porque sabemos detectar qué está mal en una situación. Si quiero cruzar la calle, ¿es seguro cruzar? Tienes que contrarrestar eso. Tienes que decir: "Vamos a suspender el juicio por un momento. Hagamos un ejercicio donde tomemos estos 10 nombres que creemos que podrían funcionar y veamos qué vamos a hacer con ellos."
context: David is giving advice to founders and product teams who need to come up with names themselves. He explains that people often create lists of 200 names but don't think they're good enough, when they actually need 1,000-1,500 names and directions. David identifies a key problem: there's too much evaluation and not enough speculation. He explains this stems from human survival instincts that make us naturally look for what's wrong with things.
vocabulary_highlights: overevaluation, suspend judgment, what are we going to do with it

speaker: David Singleton
speaker_expertise: Product Management, Engineering Leadership, Team Building
text: So we decided to co-create the product with them. So we had shared Slack channels, we'd actually show them product on a very regular basis, get their feedback on it. And only when that original kind of Alpha group was super, super happy with the product did we then think it might be ready to go to a broader audience.
text_ko: 그래서 저희는 그들과 함께 제품을 공동으로 개발하기로 했어요 (co-create). 슬랙(Slack) 공유 채널을 만들고, 아주 자주 제품을 보여드리며 피드백을 받았어요. 그리고 그 초기 알파 그룹(Alpha group)이 제품에 정말, 정말 만족할 때에야 비로소 더 많은 사람들에게 공개해도 되겠다고 판단했어요.
text_zh: 所以我们决定跟他们一起共创产品。我们建了共享的Slack频道，定期给他们看产品demo，听取他们的反馈意见。只有当最初那批Alpha用户对产品特别满意了，我们才觉得可以推向更大的用户群体。
text_es: Entonces decidimos co-crear el producto junto con ellos. Teníamos canales compartidos de Slack, les enseñábamos el producto de manera muy regular, y recibíamos su feedback. Y solo cuando ese grupo Alpha original estaba súper contento con el producto, ahí sí pensamos que ya podría estar listo para un público más amplio.
context: Lenny asks David about how Stripe builds products without traditional product managers. David explains Stripe's approach using Stripe Billing as an example, where they identified existing users like Figma and Slack who had subscription business models but were pushing the boundaries of what was possible with existing payment solutions. David describes how Stripe involves select users directly in the product development process rather than building in isolation.
vocabulary_highlights: co-create, Alpha group, super, super happy, broader audience

speaker: David Singleton
speaker_expertise: Product Management, Engineering Leadership, Team Building
text: And that means that every engineer building product at Stripe really has many of the kind of attributes and will exercise many of the attributes that you'll often find in PMs in other companies.
text_ko: 그 말은 Stripe에서 제품을 만드는 모든 엔지니어들이 다른 회사의 프로덕트 매니저들(Product Managers)에게서 흔히 볼 수 있는 여러 특성들을 많이 갖고 있고, 실제로도 그런 특성들을 자주 발휘한다는 뜻이에요.
text_zh: 这就意味着在Stripe做产品开发的每个工程师，其实都具备了很多其他公司产品经理(PM)才有的那些素质和能力，而且在实际工作中也会用到这些技能。
text_es: Y eso significa que cada ingeniero que desarrolla producto en Stripe realmente tiene muchas de las cualidades y va a ejercer muchas de las habilidades que normalmente encuentras en los PMs (product managers) de otras empresas.
context: David continues explaining Stripe's unique product development approach where they co-create products with early users through shared channels and regular feedback loops. He's describing how this collaborative, user-centric process requires Stripe engineers to develop product management skills that are typically handled by dedicated PMs at other companies. This explains how Stripe was able to delay hiring their first product manager until around their 200th employee.
vocabulary_highlights: exercise many of the attributes

speaker: David Singleton
speaker_expertise: Product Management, Engineering Leadership, Team Building
text: The way that we kind of figure out where to be meticulous, where to really sweat the details and go above and beyond is again, we try to be as user first as we possibly can.
text_ko: 어디에 꼼꼼히 신경 써야 하고 디테일까지 챙겨서 기대 이상으로 해내야 할지를 결정하는 기준은 결국 우리가 가능한 한 사용자 우선(user-first)을 지향하려고 노력하는 거예요.
text_zh: 我们怎么判断哪些地方要特别较真儿，哪些细节要死磕到底、做到极致呢？还是那句话，我们尽可能地以用户为先。
text_es: La forma en que decidimos dónde ser súper detallistas, dónde realmente esforzarnos al máximo y dar ese extra, es tratando de poner al usuario primero en todo lo que hacemos.
context: Lenny asks David about Stripe's operating principle of 'being meticulous in your craft' and how they balance perfectionism with shipping products. David explains that being meticulous everywhere would slow progress, so Stripe uses a user-first approach to determine where to invest extra effort. He's setting up to explain their 'friction logging' process, which helps them identify the most impactful areas to focus their meticulous attention on.
vocabulary_highlights: sweat the details, go above and beyond

speaker: David Singleton
speaker_expertise: Product Management, Engineering Leadership, Team Building
text: And by the way, the example I gave you on the error message is there's actually more code in the jobs that serve the Stripe API to handle those edge cases than in the actual main flow.
text_ko: 참고로, 제가 오류 메시지 예로 든 경우에는 Stripe API를 다루는 작업(jobs)에 그런 엣지 케이스(edge cases)를 처리하는 코드가 메인 흐름(main flow)보다 더 많아요.
text_zh: 顺便说一下，我刚才举的那个错误信息的例子，实际情况是这样的：在调用Stripe API的那些任务里，专门处理各种异常情况的代码，比主流程的代码还要多。
text_es: Y por cierto, el ejemplo que te di del mensaje de error... resulta que en realidad hay más código en los trabajos que sirven la API de Stripe para manejar esos casos extremos (edge cases) que en el flujo principal.
context: David is explaining how Stripe implements their 'meticulous craft' principle through specific examples. He previously mentioned how Stripe's error messages link directly to relevant documentation to help developers solve problems quickly. Now he's revealing the technical effort behind this seemingly simple feature - they actually write more code to handle error scenarios and edge cases than for the primary user flow, which demonstrates their commitment to exceptional user experience.
vocabulary_highlights: edge cases, main flow

speaker: David Singleton
speaker_expertise: Product Management, Engineering Leadership, Team Building
text: It starts with our operating principles. So because we have operating principles of users first and being meticulous in our craft, we actually tend, all of our ways of building plans tend to be wired quite well around this idea that we're going to reserve enough time to really make the experience good.
text_ko: 이건 우리 운영 원칙(operating principles)에서 시작해요. 사용자 우선(users first)과 일에 대한 꼼꼼함(being meticulous in our craft)을 기준으로 삼다 보니, 저희가 계획을 세우는 방식은 모두 경험을 진짜 좋게 만들 수 있을 만큼 충분한 시간을 확보하는 쪽으로 자연스럽게 짜여 있어요.
text_zh: 这要从我们的运营原则说起。因为我们的运营原则就是用户至上，还有就是在产品打磨上特别较真儿，所以我们在制定各种计划的时候，基本上都会围绕着一个理念，就是一定要留出足够的时间来真正把用户体验做好。
text_es: Todo empieza con nuestros principios operativos. Como tenemos esos principios de poner a los usuarios primero y ser muy meticulosos en lo que hacemos, la verdad es que todas nuestras formas de armar planes tienden a estar muy bien estructuradas alrededor de esta idea de que vamos a reservar el tiempo suficiente para realmente hacer que la experiencia sea buena.
context: Lenny asks how Stripe gives teams space to work on improvements identified through friction logging without stressing out PMs who have existing goals and timelines. David explains that their operating principles aren't just abstract values but actually drive how they plan and allocate resources. Because 'users first' and 'being meticulous' are core principles, teams naturally build buffer time into their roadmaps for experience improvements and operational fixes.
vocabulary_highlights: wired quite well around, reserve enough time

speaker: David Singleton
speaker_expertise: Product Management, Engineering Leadership, Team Building
text: I personally try to be as friendly and unscary as possible, but I know that no matter how much I do that, these can't be high stakes meetings.
text_ko: 개인적으로는 최대한 친근하고 부담스럽지 않게 하려고 해요. 다만 아무리 그래도 이런 회의는 중대한(high-stakes) 자리가 될 수 없다는 걸 알고 있어요.
text_zh: 我个人尽量表现得友好一些，不让人觉得有压迫感，但我知道不管我怎么努力，这种会议的压力还是很大的。
text_es: Personalmente trato de ser lo más amigable y accesible posible, pero sé que por más que haga eso, estas no pueden ser reuniones de mucha presión.
context: Lenny asks for advice on how product managers and designers should prepare for UX reviews with executives, noting that presenting to a CTO can be very stressful. David acknowledges that despite his efforts to create a welcoming environment, these meetings inherently carry high stakes for the people presenting. He's about to give advice on how to handle such situations by focusing on user needs rather than trying to impress leadership.
vocabulary_highlights: unscary, high stakes meetings

speaker: David Singleton
speaker_expertise: Product Management, Engineering Leadership, Team Building
text: The way we get to the name of the tower, at least the way I think about it is what you do on engineer occasion is I'll clear several days in a road, three or four days actually join a team, pick up a small task, hopefully a small feature that we can get all the way from start to finish in production and do that going through the exact experience the team has.
text_ko: 제가 그 타워 이름을 짓는 방식은, 적어도 제 생각에는, 엔지니어로서 일할 때 며칠 연속으로 시간을 비워두고(보통 3~4일) 실제로 팀에 합류해서 작은 작업—가능하면 시작부터 프로덕션(production)까지 완전히 끝낼 수 있는 작은 기능(feature)을 하나 맡아 팀이 겪는 정확한 경험을 그대로 해보는 거예요.
text_zh: 我们给这个项目起名的思路是这样的，至少我是这么想的，就是我会时不时地空出几天时间，三四天吧，直接加入团队，挑一个小任务，最好是能从头到尾完整上线的小功能，然后亲自体验一下团队的整个工作流程。
text_es: La forma en que llegamos al nombre de la torre, al menos como yo lo veo, es que de vez en cuando como ingeniero me libero varios días en el calendario, tres o cuatro días, me uno a un equipo, agarro una tarea pequeña, ojalá una funcionalidad chica que podamos llevar desde el inicio hasta el final en producción, y hago eso pasando por exactamente la misma experiencia que tiene el equipo.
context: David is explaining his concept of 'engineerications' - a portmanteau of 'engineer' and 'vacation.' Lenny asked about how David stays hands-on as a CTO. David describes how he periodically clears his executive calendar for 3-4 days to work as an individual contributor engineer, joining a team to build a small feature from start to finish. This gives him direct experience with the company's developer tools, processes, and day-to-day engineering challenges.
vocabulary_highlights: clear several days in a road, start to finish

speaker: Deb Liu
text: Some of the best PMs I have ever worked with are terrible PMs for their career. They just drift from job to job. "Hey, should I take this role or this role? How do I think about this?" But if I said you had to write a spec for your career, what does success look like? How are you going to get there?
text_ko: 제가 함께 일해본 최고의 제품 관리자(PM)들 중 몇몇은 정작 자기 커리어 관리에는 형편없어요. 그냥 계획 없이 이직만 해요. "이 역할 할까, 저 역할 할까? 어떻게 생각해야 하지?" 이런 식이죠. 그런데 만약 제가 당신에게 자신의 커리어에 대한 스펙(spec)을 작성해 보라고 한다면, 성공은 어떤 모습일까요? 거기까지 어떻게 갈 거예요?
text_zh: 我合作过的一些最厉害的产品经理(PM)，在职业规划上反而特别糟糕。他们就是这儿干干，那儿跳跳，总是在纠结"诶，我是选这个职位还是那个职位？这事儿我该怎么想？"但如果我让你给自己的职业生涯写个需求文档(spec)，你觉得成功是什么样的？你打算怎么达到那个目标？
text_es: Algunos de los mejores PMs con los que he trabajado son pésimos administrando su propia carrera. Van saltando de trabajo en trabajo sin rumbo fijo. "Oye, ¿me conviene este puesto o el otro? ¿Cómo lo veo?" Pero si les dijera que tienen que hacer un spec de su carrera, ¿cómo se vería el éxito? ¿Cómo van a llegar ahí?
context: Lenny asks Deb about career advice based on her impressive trajectory from VP of Product at Facebook to CEO of Ancestry. Deb explains a paradox she's observed in product management - many excellent PMs who are skilled at creating detailed product specifications and roadmaps completely fail to apply those same strategic thinking skills to their own careers. She argues that people should treat their career development with the same intentionality and planning they bring to product management.
vocabulary_highlights: drift from job to job, write a spec for

speaker: Deb Liu
text: Always be learning, and I tell this to everybody, so I often tell people, someone who's always learning is always going to exceed someone who's the expert today. You're going to find people... The one thing about school is that we go to school and there's such a thing as getting a hundred on the test, a perfect score on the SAT, graduating with a 4.0. Well, there's nothing like that in careers, right?
text_ko: 항상 배우세요. 이 말을 누구에게나 해요. 계속 배우는 사람은 오늘의 전문가보다 결국 더 앞서게 돼요. 학교에선 시험에서 100점 맞거나 SAT(SAT) 만점을 받거나 평점 4.0(4.0 GPA)으로 졸업하는 식의 딱 맞아떨어지는 기준이 있잖아요. 그런데 직장에선 그런 건 없어요.
text_zh: 要一直学习，我跟所有人都这么说，我经常跟大家讲，一个一直在学习的人肯定会超过那些现在是专家的人。你会发现...上学的时候吧，我们可以考满分，SAT能拿满分，能拿4.0的GPA毕业。但是在职场上，根本就没有这种满分的概念，对吧？
text_es: Siempre mantente aprendiendo, esto se lo digo a todo el mundo, así que a menudo le digo a la gente: alguien que siempre está aprendiendo va a superar a alguien que es el experto de hoy. Te vas a encontrar con gente... Lo que pasa con la escuela es que vamos a estudiar y existe eso de sacar un diez en el examen, una puntuación perfecta en el SAT, graduarte con promedio perfecto. Pero en el mundo profesional no existe nada así, ¿verdad?
context: Lenny asks Deb for one specific piece of career advice based on what has worked well for her across multiple successful roles at companies like Facebook, PayPal, and Ancestry. Deb emphasizes that continuous learning is more valuable than being an expert in any single area, because careers are fundamentally different from academic environments where there are clear metrics for perfection. She explains that professional success is non-linear and there's always room for improvement in different skills.
vocabulary_highlights: exceed someone, perfect score, non-linear experience

speaker: Deb Liu
text: The workplace is really favoring people who can speak up. It looks like self-promotion. I wouldn't want to do that because it's self-promotion. But instead, what if I called it educating about all the great work your team has been doing? Helping people see why your team should get more resources, you have to actually share what you do.
text_ko: 요즘 직장은 자기 의견을 잘 말하는 사람들에게 확실히 유리해요. 그런데 그게 자기 홍보(self-promotion)처럼 보일 수 있어서, 저도 그런 건 하기 싫을 거예요. 대신 이렇게 바꿔 생각해 보면 어떨까요? '팀이 해온 훌륭한 일들을 알리는 것'이라고 부르는 거예요. 사람들이 왜 우리 팀이 더 많은 자원(resources)을 받아야 하는지 이해하게 하려면, 실제로 우리가 하는 일을 공유해야 해요.
text_zh: 现在职场真的很看重那些敢说话、会表达的人。这看起来像是自我推销，我本来不太想这么做，因为感觉就是在自我推销嘛。但是换个思路，如果我把这叫做"宣传团队的优秀工作成果"呢？帮助大家看到为什么你的团队应该获得更多资源，你就必须真正地把你们做的事情分享出来。
text_es: El ambiente laboral realmente favorece a las personas que saben hacerse notar. Parece autopromoción, y yo no querría hacer eso porque es autopromoción. Pero, ¿y si mejor lo llamamos educar sobre todo el gran trabajo que ha estado haciendo tu equipo? Para ayudar a que la gente vea por qué tu equipo debería recibir más recursos, tienes que compartir lo que hacen en realidad.
context: Lenny references Deb's post about the challenges introverts face in achieving career success. Deb explains that modern workplaces tend to reward extroverted behaviors like speaking up and self-promotion, which can disadvantage introverted employees. She offers a reframing technique to help introverts overcome their discomfort with self-promotion by thinking of it as education and advocacy for their team's work rather than personal aggrandizement.
vocabulary_highlights: speak up, self-promotion, get more resources
topics: Career Development, Communication Skills, Leadership & Management

speaker: Deb Liu
text: The people who were most successful were the ones who actually through adversity, learned to turn stumbling blocks into stepping stones. They were the ones who got hard feedback and then came back stronger because now they learned what to do differently. They were the ones who products failed, but they said, "You know what? I'm going to turn this failure into success. I'm going to take those lessons and make this company stronger."
text_ko: 가장 성공한 사람들은 역경 속에서 걸림돌을 디딤돌로 바꾸는 법을 배운 사람들이에요. 그들은 힘든 피드백(hard feedback)을 받고도 더 강해져서 돌아왔어요. 무엇을 다르게 해야 하는지 배웠기 때문이에요. 제품이 실패했을 때도 “이 실패를 성공으로 바꿀 거예요. 배운 걸 살려 회사를 더 강하게 만들 거예요”라고 말하고 실제로 그렇게 만든 사람들이에요.
text_zh: 最成功的那些人，其实都是在逆境中学会了化阻力为动力的人。他们接受了严厉的反馈意见后，反而变得更强了，因为现在他们知道该怎么做不同的调整。他们的产品失败了，但他们会说："你知道吗？我要把这次失败变成成功。我要吸取这些教训，让公司变得更强大。"
text_es: Las personas que tuvieron más éxito fueron las que, a través de las adversidades, aprendieron a convertir los obstáculos en oportunidades. Fueron las que recibieron críticas duras y regresaron más fuertes porque ya sabían qué hacer diferente. Fueron las que vieron fallar sus productos, pero dijeron: "¿Sabes qué? Voy a convertir este fracaso en éxito. Voy a tomar esas lecciones aprendidas y hacer que esta empresa sea más fuerte."
context: Lenny asks Deb about her perspective on failure and resilience in career success. Deb shares her observation from coaching many people and managing large teams that the most successful individuals aren't those who avoided failure, but rather those who learned to transform setbacks into opportunities for growth. She uses the metaphor of turning stumbling blocks into stepping stones to illustrate how resilient people leverage adversity to build strength and achieve greater success.
vocabulary_highlights: turn stumbling blocks into stepping stones, came back stronger, turn this failure into success
topics: Career Development, Learning & Growth, Leadership & Management

speaker: Deb Liu
text: I really saw my opportunity in Facebook to be somebody that zigged when other people zagged. There were amazing people who did a lot of the really core products working on feed, photos, videos. I came in actually on the payments team and we worked on payments and eventually built games, which was the first billion dollar business.
text_ko: 페이스북에서는 남들이 다들 하는 방향과는 다르게 움직이는 사람으로 기회를 잡을 수 있겠다고 정말 느꼈어요. 피드(feed), 사진(photos), 동영상(videos) 같은 핵심 제품을 맡아 만든 놀라운 사람들이 많았고요. 저는 사실 결제(payments) 팀으로 들어가 결제 일을 했는데, 그 과정에서 결국 게임(games)을 만들었고 그게 회사의 첫 10억 달러 규모 사업(billion-dollar business)이었어요.
text_zh: 我当时在Facebook真的看到了一个机会，就是别人都往东走的时候我往西走。当时有很多牛人在做核心产品，搞信息流、照片、视频这些。我其实是从支付团队进去的，我们做支付相关的东西，后来搭建了游戏业务，这也是公司第一个十亿美金的业务。
text_es: Realmente vi mi oportunidad en Facebook para ser alguien que fuera por un lado cuando todos los demás iban por el otro. Había gente increíble que trabajaba en los productos principales más importantes - el feed, las fotos, los videos. Yo entré en el equipo de pagos y trabajamos en todo el tema de payments y al final construimos los juegos, que fue el primer negocio de mil millones de dólares.
context: Lenny asks Deb about her approach to building zero-to-one businesses within Facebook, noting that she built multiple billion-dollar products like Facebook Marketplace and ad platforms. Deb explains her strategic approach of deliberately choosing to work on areas that others weren't focusing on, rather than competing in crowded spaces like core social features. This contrarian strategy allowed her to build significant new revenue streams for the company, starting with the games business which became Facebook's first billion-dollar vertical.
vocabulary_highlights: zigged when other people zagged, core products
topics: Strategy & Planning, Product Management, Starting a Company

speaker: Deb Liu
text: I think the most important part of the environment is really patience. And again, this is a portfolio strategy and I tell every PM who... I used to do a new hire PM class and I say, "Look, a lot of you are going to go into the core product and your job is to grow X by 3 to 5% every six months. Growing engagement or growing sessions or maybe growing video views or whatever your metric is, you're trying to grow something 5% and then you exceed expectations."
text_ko: 저는 그런 환경에서 가장 중요한 건 진짜 인내심이라고 생각해요. 그리고 다시 말하지만, 이건 포트폴리오 전략(portfolio strategy)이에요. 저는 모든 프로덕트 매니저(PM, product manager)에게 늘 이렇게 말해요. 예전엔 신입 PM 수업을 맡아서 학생들한테 항상 말했는데요, “보세요, 여러분 중 많은 분이 핵심 제품(core product)에 들어가게 될 거고, 여러분의 임무는 매 6개월마다 X를 3~5% 정도 성장시키는 거예요. 참여도(engagement)를 늘리거나 세션 수(sessions)를 늘리거나 동영상 조회수(video views)를 늘리거나, 어떤 지표든 간에 뭔가를 5% 정도 키우려는 게 목표고, 그걸 넘기면 기대치를 초과하는 거예요.”
text_zh: 我觉得环境中最重要的其实就是耐心。再说一遍，这是一个组合策略(portfolio strategy)，我跟每个PM都这么说过... 我以前给新入职的PM上课时会说："听着，你们很多人会进入核心产品团队，你的工作就是每六个月把某个指标提升3到5%。不管是提升用户参与度、增加会话数，还是增加视频播放量，或者其他什么指标，你就是要把某个东西提升5%，然后超出预期。"
text_es: Creo que lo más importante del entorno es realmente la paciencia. Y otra vez, esto es una estrategia de portafolio y le digo a cada PM que... yo solía dar una clase para PMs recién contratados y les decía: "Miren, muchos de ustedes van a ir al producto principal (core product) y su trabajo va a ser hacer crecer X entre 3 a 5% cada seis meses. Hacer crecer el engagement o las sesiones o tal vez las visualizaciones de video o cualquiera que sea su métrica, están tratando de hacer crecer algo un 5% y después superar las expectativas."
context: Lenny asks Deb about tactics for creating an environment where new zero-to-one products can succeed within large companies without being over-scrutinized or killed prematurely. Deb explains that patience is crucial and describes how she would educate new product managers about the different career paths available - working on core products with predictable growth targets versus taking the higher-risk path of building something entirely new from scratch.
vocabulary_highlights: portfolio strategy, core product, exceed expectations
topics: Product Management, Strategy & Planning, Career Development

speaker: Dhanji R. Prasanna
text: We see a significant amount of games. We find engineering teams that are very, very AI forward are reporting about eight to 10 hours save per week. Whenever I hear a stat like this, I think an important element is this is the worst it will ever be. This is now the baseline. The truth is the value is changing every day, so you need to ride that wave along with it.
text_ko: 우리는 상당한 수준의 성과를 보고 있어요. 매우 AI 지향(AI-forward)이 강한 엔지니어링 팀들은 주당 약 8~10시간을 절약한다고 보고해요. 이런 통계를 들을 때마다 저는 한 가지 중요한 점이 떠올라요. 이건 지금이 앞으로 가장 나쁠 때라는 뜻이에요. 이제 이게 기준선(baseline)이 된 거고요. 사실 가치는 날마다 변하고 있으니, 그 변화의 파도를 함께 타야 해요.
text_zh: 我们看到很多公司都在玩各种花样。我们发现那些在AI方面走得很前的工程团队，他们说每周能节省8到10个小时。每当我听到这种数据，我觉得有个重要点就是——这已经是最差的情况了，这就是个起点。事实上价值每天都在变，所以你得跟上这个浪潮。
text_es: Vemos una cantidad considerable de juegos. Nos encontramos con equipos de ingeniería que están muy, muy enfocados en IA y nos reportan que se ahorran entre ocho y diez horas por semana. Cada vez que escucho una estadística así, pienso que algo importante es que esto es lo peor que va a estar. Este es ahora el punto de partida. La realidad es que el valor está cambiando todos los días, así que tienes que montarte en esa ola y seguirla.
context: Lenny asks about productivity gains from AI, noting there are camps of both AI optimists and skeptics. Dhanji responds with concrete data from Block's experience with AI tools. He explains that AI-forward engineering teams at Block are self-reporting significant time savings, but emphasizes that AI capabilities are rapidly improving, so companies need to continuously adapt and evolve their AI strategies rather than expecting static benefits.
vocabulary_highlights: ride that wave, AI forward, baseline

speaker: Dhanji R. Prasanna
text: What's been surprising and really amazing, the non-technical people using AI agents and programming tools to build things, the people that are able to embrace it to optimize for their particular workday and their particular set of tasks are really showing the most impact from these tools.
text_ko: 정말 놀랍고 인상적인 건, 기술 배경이 없는 사람들이 AI 에이전트(AI agents)와 프로그래밍 도구(programming tools)를 활용해 자신만의 근무 방식과 업무에 맞게 하루 일과를 최적화하는 사람들이 이 도구들로부터 가장 큰 효과를 보고 있다는 점이에요.
text_zh: 特别让人意外也很厉害的是，那些非技术背景的人用AI代理(AI agents)和编程工具来做东西，那些能够拥抱这些技术、针对自己具体的工作日程和任务去优化的人，他们从这些工具中获得的效果是最明显的。
text_es: Lo que ha sido sorprendente y realmente increíble es ver cómo la gente no técnica está usando agentes de IA (AI agents) y herramientas de programación (programming tools) para crear cosas. Las personas que logran adoptarlas para optimizar su día a día laboral y sus tareas específicas son las que están viendo el mayor impacto de estas herramientas.
context: Lenny asks which level of engineer benefits most from AI tools - junior or senior engineers. Dhanji reveals a surprising finding that goes against common assumptions. Rather than engineers being the primary beneficiaries, non-technical employees like legal, risk, and support teams are seeing the greatest productivity gains by using AI to build custom software tools for their specific workflows and needs.
vocabulary_highlights: embrace it, optimize for

speaker: Dhanji R. Prasanna
text: All these LLMs are sitting idle overnight and on weekends, while humans aren't there. There's no need for that. They should be working all the time. They should be trying to build in anticipation of what we want.
text_ko: 대형 언어 모델(LLMs)들이 밤이든 주말이든 사람이 없을 때 가만히 유휴 상태로 있는 건 필요 없어요. 24시간 작동해서 우리가 원할 걸 미리 예측하고 그에 맞춰 계속 뭔가를 만들어내려고 해야 해요.
text_zh: 这些大语言模型(LLM)晚上和周末都闲着，人不在的时候就停工了，完全没必要嘛。应该让它们24小时不停地干活，提前琢磨我们想要什么，把东西准备好。
text_es: Todos estos LLMs se quedan ahí sin hacer nada por las noches y los fines de semana, cuando no está la gente. No tiene sentido. Deberían estar trabajando todo el tiempo. Deberían estar intentando construir cosas anticipándose a lo que queremos.
context: Lenny asks how Dhanji thinks engineering work will look different in a couple of years. Dhanji envisions a future where AI agents work continuously, not just during human work hours. He describes AI systems that could work overnight and on weekends, proactively building features and solutions in anticipation of human needs, rather than the current model where AI tools only work when humans are actively using them.
vocabulary_highlights: sitting idle, in anticipation of

speaker: Dhanji R. Prasanna
text: A lot of engineers think that code quality is important to building a successful product. The two have nothing to do with each other.
text_ko: 많은 엔지니어들이 코드 품질(code quality)이 성공적인 제품을 만드는 데 중요하다고 생각해요. 그런데 사실 둘은 전혀 상관없어요.
text_zh: 很多工程师都觉得代码质量对做出成功产品很重要。其实这俩压根儿就没什么关系。
text_es: Muchos ingenieros creen que la calidad del código es clave para construir un producto exitoso. En realidad, una cosa no tiene nada que ver with la otra.
context: Lenny asks about the most counterintuitive lesson Dhanji has learned about building products or teams. Dhanji challenges a core belief held by many engineers about the relationship between code quality and product success. This statement goes against conventional software engineering wisdom that emphasizes clean, well-architected code as essential for product success.
vocabulary_highlights: have nothing to do with each other

speaker: Dhanji R. Prasanna
text: So everything from getting the top ICs in the company together to talk to each other, to starting a whole bunch of special projects. So we got about two to five engineers per project. There were about eight or nine different projects and we had reinstituted, the company-wide hack week.
text_ko: 그래서 회사 내 핵심 IC들(Individual Contributors)을 모아 서로 얘기하게 하는 것부터 여러 특화 프로젝트를 시작하는 것까지 다 했어요. 프로젝트당 엔지니어는 대략 2~5명 정도였고, 서로 다른 프로젝트가 8~9개 정도 있었어요. 그리고 전사 해커톤 주간(hack week)을 다시 도입했어요.
text_zh: 所以我们做了很多事情，比如把公司里最牛的那些个人贡献者(individual contributors)聚到一起互相交流，还启动了一堆特殊项目。每个项目大概配了2到5个工程师，总共有八九个不同的项目，然后我们还重新搞起了全公司的黑客周(hack week)。
text_es: Entonces, desde juntar a los mejores ICs (individual contributors) de la empresa para que se pongan a platicar entre ellos, hasta arrancar un montón de proyectos especiales. Metimos como dos a cinco ingenieros por proyecto. Fueron como ocho o nueve proyectos diferentes y reinstauramos la semana de hack (hack week) a nivel de toda la compañía.
context: Lenny asks about the bigger changes Dhanji made after getting executive buy-in for his AI manifesto. Dhanji explains his strategy for transforming Block back into a technology-first company. He describes implementing several programs designed to reignite the engineering culture, including bringing together top individual contributors (ICs), launching multiple small experimental projects, and restarting company-wide hackathons to create momentum around building innovative technology.
vocabulary_highlights: top ICs, reinstituted, company-wide hack week

speaker: Dhanji R. Prasanna
text: I think that one of the things that I learned the most throughout this process is that Conway's Law can be really, really powerful. So it's the law that basically says you ship your org structure. So what you're organized as in terms of teams, in terms of collaborating groups and your operating model matters a lot to what you build.
text_ko: 이번 과정을 통해 가장 많이 배운 것 중 하나는 콘웨이의 법칙(Conway's Law)이 정말, 정말 강력하다는 거예요. 이 법칙은 기본적으로 조직 구조가 그대로 제품에 반영된다는 의미예요. 즉 팀 구성이나 협업 단위, 운영 모델(operating model)이 어떻게 돼 있느냐에 따라 결국 무엇을 만들게 될지가 크게 달라진다는 뜻이에요.
text_zh: 我觉得在整个过程中学到最深刻的一点就是，康威定律(Conway's Law)真的特别厉害。这个定律基本上就是说，你交付的产品会反映你的组织架构。所以你的团队怎么组织的，协作小组怎么搭建的，还有你的运营模式，这些对你最终做出来的东西影响特别大。
text_es: Creo que una de las cosas que más aprendí en todo este proceso es que la Ley de Conway puede ser súper poderosa. Básicamente es la ley que dice que terminas creando productos que reflejan cómo está organizada tu empresa. O sea, cómo tienes armados los equipos, los grupos que colaboran y tu modelo operativo influye muchísimo en lo que construyes al final.
context: Lenny asks how Block's engineering teams work differently today versus a few years ago. Dhanji reflects on the organizational transformation from GM structure to functional structure and explains a key insight he gained. Conway's Law states that organizations design systems that mirror their communication structure - meaning the way teams are organized directly influences the products they create. This was a crucial realization in Block's transformation to become more technically focused.
vocabulary_highlights: Conway's Law, you ship your org structure, operating model

speaker: Dharmesh Shah
speaker_expertise: Company Building, Executive Coaching, Engineering Leadership
text: I could become passively okay at management with some training, with some coaching. I don't want to spend any years of my life becoming passively okay at something.
text_ko: 교육이나 코칭을 받으면 그저 그럭저럭 괜찮은 관리자는 될 수 있어요. 그런데 제 인생의 몇 년을 그런 '그저 괜찮은' 상태로 보내고 싶지는 않아요.
text_zh: 通过培训和指导，我可能会成为一个还算过得去的管理者。但我不想把人生中的几年时间花在做一个"还算过得去"的事情上。
text_es: Podría llegar a ser un gerente pasable con algo de capacitación, con un poco de coaching. No quiero desperdiciar años de mi vida volviéndome apenas pasable en algo.
context: Lenny asks Dharmesh about his decision to never have direct reports at HubSpot. Dharmesh explains that during the founding of HubSpot, he realized he wasn't naturally good at management and had failed at it in previous companies. Rather than spending years trying to become mediocre at something he didn't enjoy, he chose to focus his energy on things he was naturally good at and passionate about.
vocabulary_highlights: passively okay, spend any years of my life

speaker: Dharmesh Shah
speaker_expertise: Company Building, Executive Coaching, Engineering Leadership
text: It comes down to this metric that stand-up comedians use called LPM laughs per minute. I have custom software that I've written that will say, 'Okay, here are the points at which the audience laugh.'
text_ko: 결국 스탠드업 코미디언들이 쓰는 LPM(분당 웃음 수, laughs per minute)이라는 지표로 귀결돼요. 제가 직접 만든 맞춤형 소프트웨어가 있어서 관객이 웃는 지점을 정확히 짚어줘요.
text_zh: 说白了就是脱口秀演员用的那个指标，叫每分钟笑点数(LPM - laughs per minute)。我专门写了个软件，能告诉我"好，观众在这些地方笑了"。
text_es: Al final se reduce a esta métrica que usan los comediantes que se llama LPM, risas por minuto (laughs per minute). Tengo un software personalizado que yo mismo desarrollé que me dice: "Mira, estos son los momentos exactos donde se ríe la audiencia."
context: Lenny asks about Dharmesh's unique approach to preparing keynote speeches. Dharmesh explains how he applies engineering principles to public speaking by measuring audience engagement. He records his practice talks, transcribes them, and uses custom software to calculate laughs per minute (LPM) - a metric borrowed from stand-up comedy - to optimize his presentations for maximum audience attention.
vocabulary_highlights: laughs per minute, custom software

speaker: Dharmesh Shah
speaker_expertise: Company Building, Executive Coaching, Engineering Leadership
text: Some of the best startup advice I've heard is startups should focus on one thing and be really, really exceptionally world-class at that one thing. And one of our early zigs is we are going to do exactly the opposite of that.
text_ko: 제가 들은 최고의 스타트업(startups) 조언 중 하나는, 스타트업은 한 가지에 집중해서 그 한 가지에서 정말, 정말 탁월하게 세계 최고가 돼야 한다는 거예요. 그런데 저희가 초반에 한 '지그'(zigs) 중 하나는 바로 그걸 정확히 정반대로 해보겠다는 거예요.
text_zh: 我听过最好的创业建议之一就是，创业公司应该专注做一件事，而且要把这件事做到世界顶级水平。但我们早期的策略恰恰相反，我们要反其道而行之。
text_es: Uno de los mejores consejos para startups que he escuchado es que deberían enfocarse en una sola cosa y ser realmente, pero realmente excepcionales a nivel mundial en esa cosa. Y una de nuestras primeras movidas contrarias es que vamos a hacer exactamente lo opuesto a eso.
context: Lenny asks Dharmesh about his tendency to 'zig when others zag' - making contrarian business decisions. Dharmesh explains one of HubSpot's biggest contrarian bets: instead of focusing on becoming the best at one specific tool, they built an all-in-one platform with multiple products. This went against conventional startup wisdom but solved the real customer problem of SMBs struggling to integrate multiple separate tools.
vocabulary_highlights: world-class, early zigs

speaker: Dharmesh Shah
speaker_expertise: Company Building, Executive Coaching, Engineering Leadership
text: I think too many founders, once they get to a... They are very apprehensive of going public and going through the IPO process and being a publicly traded company because they think... I mean, that's like the beginning of the end.
text_ko: 제 생각에는 많은 창업자들이 어느 정도 성장하면 상장(going public)이나 IPO 과정(IPO process)을 거쳐 상장사(publicly traded company)이 되는 걸 지나치게 꺼려해요. 그들은 그게 사실상 끝의 시작이라고 생각하거든요.
text_zh: 我觉得太多创始人，一旦他们到了那个阶段...他们对上市特别抵触，不愿意走IPO流程，也不想成为公开交易的公司，因为他们觉得...这就像是走下坡路的开始。
text_es: Creo que muchos fundadores, una vez que llegan a cierto punto... Les da mucho miedo salir a bolsa y pasar por todo el proceso de la OPI (IPO) y convertirse en una empresa que cotiza en bolsa porque piensan... O sea, es como el principio del fin.
context: Lenny asks what lessons Dharmesh has learned from being a public company executive for nearly 10 years. Dharmesh shares his contrarian view that founders are unnecessarily afraid of going public. He argues that while there are additional requirements for public companies, there are significant benefits including real-time market valuation feedback and allowing broader public participation in the company's growth.
vocabulary_highlights: apprehensive, beginning of the end

speaker: Dharmesh Shah
speaker_expertise: Company Building, Executive Coaching, Engineering Leadership
text: Culture is a product, period, and that every company builds two products, one is the product they build for their customers, and the other is a product they build for their team. That's what culture is, it's the product you build for your team.
text_ko: 문화는 제품이에요, 그게 핵심이에요. 모든 회사는 사실 두 가지 제품을 만들어요: 하나는 고객을 위한 제품이고, 다른 하나는 팀을 위한 제품이에요. 그 팀을 위한 제품이 바로 문화예요.
text_zh: 企业文化就是一个产品，就这么简单。每个公司其实都在做两个产品，一个是给客户用的产品，另一个是给自己团队用的产品。企业文化就是这样，它就是你为团队打造的那个产品。
text_es: La cultura es un producto, punto. Cada empresa desarrolla dos productos: uno es lo que construyen para sus clientes, y el otro es lo que construyen para su equipo. Eso es la cultura: el producto que desarrollas para tu equipo.
context: Lenny asks Dharmesh about his process for defining and maintaining HubSpot's culture. Dharmesh shares his framework that culture should be treated as a product with employees as customers. This means regularly surveying employees like you would customers, iterating on culture based on feedback, and never considering culture 'finished' - just like you would never stop improving a customer-facing product.

speaker: Dharmesh Shah
speaker_expertise: Company Building, Executive Coaching, Engineering Leadership
text: Within a closed system, entropy increases over time. We don't have to get into the [inaudible 00:37:50] of this. In lay person's terms, the second law of thermodynamics, I'm paraphrasing here, is that, 'Over time, unless you intervene, everything goes to crap.'
text_ko: 폐쇄계(closed system)에서는 엔트로피(entropy)가 시간이 지날수록 증가해요. 그 부분의 세부사항은 굳이 들어가지 않을게요. 쉬운 말로, 열역학 제2법칙(second law of thermodynamics)을 제가 요약하면 ‘시간이 흐르면 개입하지 않는 한 모든 게 점점 엉망이 돼요’라는 뜻이에요.
text_zh: 在一个封闭系统里，熵会随着时间增加。这个我们就不深入讲了[听不清 00:37:50]。用大白话说，热力学第二定律(second law of thermodynamics)，我这里简单概括一下，就是"时间久了，你要是不管不问，什么东西都会变得一团糟。"
text_es: Dentro de un sistema cerrado, la entropía aumenta con el tiempo. No necesitamos meternos en los detalles técnicos de esto. En términos sencillos, la segunda ley de la termodinámica, parafraseando aquí, es que "con el tiempo, a menos que intervengas, todo se va al carajo."
context: Lenny asks about Dharmesh's concept that business leaders are fighting the second law of thermodynamics. Dharmesh explains that just like physical systems naturally tend toward disorder without intervention, companies naturally become more complex over time. Leaders must actively fight this entropy by simplifying processes, reducing complexity, and making conscious decisions to maintain organizational efficiency as they scale.
vocabulary_highlights: closed system, entropy, lay person's terms, goes to crap

speaker: Dmitry Zlokazov
speaker_expertise: Product Management, User Experience, Product Strategy
text: Everyone is striving for talented, skillful, smart people. Revolut values way more raw intellect and this unquenched hunger to build things rather than experience.
text_ko: 모두가 재능 있고 능숙하고 똑똑한 사람을 찾으려고 하죠. Revolut은 단순한 경력이나 경험보다 '순수한 지적 능력(raw intellect)'과 무언가를 만들어내려는 끝없는 갈망을 훨씬 더 중요하게 생각해요.
text_zh: 大家都在抢有才华、有技能、聪明的人才。但Revolut更看重的是那种天生的聪明劲儿，还有那种永远不满足、总想搞点什么出来的冲劲，而不是工作经验。
text_es: Todos andan buscando gente talentosa, hábil e inteligente. En Revolut valoramos mucho más la inteligencia pura y esas ganas enormes de construir cosas que la experiencia en sí.
context: Lenny asks Dmitry about Revolut's unique approach to hiring product managers (called product owners at Revolut). Dmitry explains that while most companies prioritize experience and credentials, Revolut takes a contrarian approach by focusing on candidates' natural intelligence and genuine passion for building products over their years of experience in the field.
vocabulary_highlights: raw intellect, unquenched hunger

speaker: Dmitry Zlokazov
speaker_expertise: Product Management, User Experience, Product Strategy
text: It's not getting traction. Is it because the underlying idea is wrong? Or maybe your product just sucks? By forcing everyone to build a product that people will love, we kind of cut out this part of uncertainty.
text_ko: 트랙션(traction)이 안 나요. 근본 아이디어가 잘못된 걸까요? 아니면 제품이 그냥 별로라서 그런 걸까요? 모두가 사람들이 좋아할 제품을 만들게끔 하다 보니, 우리는 그 불확실성 부분을 어느 정도 없앴어요.
text_zh: 这个产品就是推不动。是不是底层的想法就有问题？还是说你们的产品就是做得不行？如果我们强制要求每个人都要做出用户真正喜欢的产品，其实就把这种不确定性给排除掉了。
text_es: No está pegando. ¿Será porque la idea de fondo está mal? ¿O tal vez tu producto simplemente es una porquería? Al obligar a todos a crear un producto que la gente realmente ame, como que eliminamos esta parte de la incertidumbre.
context: Lenny asks about how Revolut approaches early product development differently from other companies. Dmitry explains their philosophy of investing heavily in product quality from the start rather than launching scrappy MVPs. He argues that when products fail to gain traction, it's often unclear whether the core idea is flawed or the execution is simply poor quality.
vocabulary_highlights: cut out this part of uncertainty

speaker: Dmitry Zlokazov
speaker_expertise: Product Management, User Experience, Product Strategy
text: If something is 99% done, it's closer to 0% rather than 100%.
text_ko: 어떤 일이 99% 끝났다고 해도, 실제로는 100%보다 0%에 더 가깝다고 봐야 해요.
text_zh: 如果一件事做了99%，那其实更接近0%，而不是100%。
text_es: Si algo está al 99%, está más cerca del 0% que del 100%.
context: Lenny asks Dmitry about what he's learned about setting up new products for success. Dmitry shares this philosophy about execution and completion, emphasizing that product owners at Revolut must be relentlessly focused on actually shipping and delivering value to customers, not just building features.

speaker: Dmitry Zlokazov
speaker_expertise: Product Management, User Experience, Product Strategy
text: We go very deep on example of each of these projects. For example, we launched a branch in Ireland, we launched a branch in Netherlands. Then we reverse engineered what was the best process to do it, and then we went back up on top level and we said, okay, but what's the ideal framework of doing it at scale?
text_ko: 저희는 각 프로젝트 사례를 하나하나 아주 깊게 파고들어요. 예를 들어 아일랜드에 지사를 세우고 네덜란드에도 지사를 열었죠. 그런 다음 어떤 프로세스가 가장 효과적이었는지 역공학(reverse-engineering)으로 분석하고, 그걸 바탕으로 상위 수준에서 다시 보며 '이걸 대규모(at scale)로 진행할 때 이상적인 프레임워크(framework)는 뭘까?'라고 정리했어요.
text_zh: 我们会深挖每个项目的具体案例。比如说，我们在爱尔兰开了分公司，在荷兰也开了分公司。然后我们就倒推分析，看看最佳流程是什么，再回到顶层去思考，那如果要大规模复制的话，理想的框架应该是什么样的？
text_es: Nos metemos a fondo con ejemplos de cada uno de estos proyectos. Por ejemplo, abrimos una sucursal en Irlanda, abrimos otra en Holanda. Después hicimos ingeniería inversa para ver cuál era el mejor proceso para hacerlo, y luego volvimos al nivel más alto y dijimos, bueno, ¿pero cuál es el marco ideal para hacerlo a gran escala?
context: Lenny asks for a specific example of what Dmitry means when he talks about product owners needing to go really deep into details. Dmitry explains how Revolut's lean team handles the complex challenge of launching banking operations across 50 countries. Rather than trying to solve everything at once, they dive deep into specific examples first, then extract learnings to create scalable processes.
vocabulary_highlights: reverse engineered, top level, at scale

speaker: Dmitry Zlokazov
speaker_expertise: Product Management, User Experience, Product Strategy
text: I would probably add an obsession with building wow product. I think in FinTech overall, this is probably the most neglected part usually, but it's also a part that we at Revolut, we pay enormous attention to.
text_ko: 저라면 '와우 제품(wow product)'을 만드는 데 대한 집착을 더하겠어요. 핀테크(FinTech) 업계 전반에서 보통 가장 소홀히 여기는 부분인데, 저희 Revolut에서는 이 부분에 엄청나게 신경 써요.
text_zh: 我觉得还要加上一点，就是要痴迷于打造让人眼前一亮的产品。整个金融科技(FinTech)行业，这块儿通常是最容易被忽视的，但在我们Revolut，这恰恰是我们最重视的地方。
text_es: Yo probablemente añadiría una obsesión por crear productos que realmente impresionen. Creo que en FinTech en general, esta es probablemente la parte que más se descuida normalmente, pero también es una parte a la que nosotros en Revolut le prestamos muchísima atención.
context: Lenny asks what else contributes to Revolut alumni product managers becoming so successful at other companies. Dmitry identifies their focus on creating 'wow' products - meaning lovable, delightful user experiences - as a key differentiator. He notes that most FinTech companies neglect the emotional and aesthetic aspects of product design, focusing only on functionality.
vocabulary_highlights: obsession with, most neglected part, pay enormous attention to

speaker: Dmitry Zlokazov
speaker_expertise: Product Management, User Experience, Product Strategy
text: Unfortunately, professionals with a lot of years of experience from established companies, they don't have this strong urge to change status quo, which by the way will require toil, tears, and sweat.
text_ko: 안타깝게도 기성 기업에서 오랜 경력을 쌓은 전문가들은 현상 유지(status quo)를 바꾸려는 강한 의지가 별로 없어요. 그런 변화는 땀과 눈물, 많은 고생을 각오해야 하거든요.
text_zh: 可惜的是，那些在大公司待了很多年的老员工，他们没有那种强烈的冲动去打破现状，而且说实话，要改变现状是需要付出很大代价的，得流汗流泪甚至流血。
text_es: Lamentablemente, los profesionales con muchos años de experiencia en empresas consolidadas no tienen esa necesidad imperiosa de cambiar las cosas como están, lo cual, por cierto, va a requerir mucho esfuerzo, sacrificio y dedicación.
context: Lenny asks about Revolut's unique hiring approach and what they look for in product managers. Dmitry explains why they prefer hiring less experienced but highly driven people over senior professionals from established companies. He argues that experienced hires often lack the hunger and willingness to do difficult work required to disrupt existing systems and build innovative products.
vocabulary_highlights: strong urge, change status quo, toil, tears, and sweat

speaker: Dmitry Zlokazov
speaker_expertise: Product Management, User Experience, Product Strategy
text: Most importantly, it's again, getting things done, getting your hands dirty, and great product owners are very hands-on. They don't think of themselves as managers who just give tasks to people and wait them to complete it.
text_ko: 가장 중요한 건, 다시 말하지만 일을 해내는 거예요. 직접 발 벗고 나서서 손도 더럽히면서요. 훌륭한 프로덕트 오너(product owner)들은 아주 실무적으로 현장에 깊이 관여해요. 그냥 사람들에게 일만 시켜놓고 완료되기만 기다리는 관리자라고 생각하지 않아요.
text_zh: 最关键的是，还是要实打实地把事情做出来，要亲自上手干活，优秀的产品负责人都是很hands-on的。他们不会把自己当成那种只会分派任务然后坐等结果的管理者。
text_es: Lo más importante es, otra vez, hacer que las cosas sucedan, meterse de lleno en el trabajo, y los grandes product owners son muy hands-on. No se ven a sí mismos como gerentes que solo reparten tareas y se quedan esperando a que otros las terminen.
context: Lenny asks what else Revolut looks for when hiring that leads to people being really successful in their careers. Dmitry emphasizes the importance of execution-focused candidates who are willing to personally tackle difficult problems rather than just delegating work. He explains that successful product owners at Revolut take personal ownership of outcomes and are willing to do whatever work is necessary themselves.
vocabulary_highlights: getting your hands dirty, hands-on

speaker: Donna Lichaw
text: We all as humans want to be the hero of our own story. It's how we live our lives, it's how we make choices, it's how we understand the world around us, and it's how we communicate back to the world. With leadership, it's much the same, which is we have a mission that we want to accomplish.
text_ko: 우리 모두 자기 이야기의 영웅이 되고 싶어 해요. 그건 우리가 삶을 살아가는 방식이고, 선택을 하는 방식이며, 주변 세상을 이해하는 방식이자 세상에 자신을 표현하는 방식이기도 해요. 리더십도 마찬가지예요. 리더십에도 우리가 이루고자 하는 미션(mission)이 있어요.
text_zh: 我们每个人都想成为自己人生故事里的主角，对吧？这就是我们的生活方式，也是我们做决定的方式，更是我们理解周围世界、跟世界沟通的方式。做领导也是一样的道理，我们都有想要实现的使命。
text_es: Todos como seres humanos queremos ser el protagonista de nuestra propia historia. Es así como vivimos, es así como tomamos decisiones, es así como entendemos el mundo que nos rodea, y es así como nos comunicamos con el mundo. Con el liderazgo pasa algo muy parecido: tenemos una misión que queremos cumplir.
context: Lenny asks Donna to explain why figuring out your own story and seeing yourself as the hero is so powerful for leadership development. Donna explains that humans naturally view themselves as the central character in their life narrative, and this same psychological principle applies to effective leadership - leaders need a clear mission and must take themselves and others somewhere meaningful.

speaker: Donna Lichaw
text: The most effective stories are the ones that we experience as we live life and that we tell ourselves as well because we have the ability by saying things like, 'Oh, I'll never succeed,' or, 'Oh, she'll never go for it,' or, 'He's such a jerk.' Or whatever the stories are, these are all stories. And they may or may not be true, they're usually not true, but our brain doesn't know the difference.
text_ko: 가장 효과적인 이야기들은 우리가 살아가면서 직접 겪고, 또 스스로에게 들려주는 이야기들이에요. 예를 들어 ‘나는 절대 성공 못해’, ‘그녀는 절대 해보지 않을 거야’, ‘저 사람은 정말 별로야’ 같은 식으로 스스로 말하는 것들이죠. 어떤 이야기든 결국 이야기일 뿐이고, 사실일 수도 있고 아닐 수도 있어요—대부분은 사실이 아닌 경우가 많아요. 그런데 우리 뇌는 그 차이를 잘 구분하지 못해요.
text_zh: 最有效的故事其实就是我们在生活中经历的那些，还有我们对自己说的那些话，因为我们总是会说一些像"哎，我肯定不会成功的"，或者"她肯定不会同意的"，或者"这人就是个混蛋"之类的。不管是什么故事，这些都是故事而已。它们可能是真的，也可能不是，通常都不是真的，但我们的大脑分不出区别。
text_es: Las historias más poderosas son las que vivimos día a día y las que nos contamos a nosotros mismos, porque tenemos esa capacidad de decirnos cosas como "Ay, nunca voy a tener éxito", o "Esa nunca va a aceptar", o "Ese tipo es un idiota". O lo que sea que nos digamos, todo eso son historias. Y pueden ser verdad o no, por lo general no lo son, pero nuestro cerebro no sabe la diferencia.
context: Donna explains why the internal stories we tell ourselves are more powerful than the stories we tell others. She emphasizes that our brains cannot distinguish between true and false narratives we create about ourselves and situations, making these internal stories incredibly influential on our behavior and outcomes as leaders.
vocabulary_highlights: she'll never go for it

speaker: Donna Lichaw
text: Take a data-driven approach to the stories that you tell yourself. For example, the story, 'I'm too nice,' it could be true, it could not be true. How did we get down to the bottom of that? In this case, what we did is I went out there and talked to his team.
text_ko: 스스로에게 하는 이야기들에는 데이터 기반으로 접근해 보세요. 예를 들어 ‘난 너무 착해’라는 이야기는 사실일 수도 있고 아닐 수도 있어요. 그걸 어떻게 확인했냐면요, 이번 경우에는 제가 직접 그분의 팀과 만나서 이야기를 들어봤어요.
text_zh: 讲故事要用数据说话，特别是你给自己讲的那些故事。比如说"我这人太好说话了"这种想法，可能是真的，也可能不是。怎么搞清楚呢？这次我们就直接去找他团队的人聊了聊。
text_es: Adopta un enfoque basado en datos para las historias que te cuentas a ti mismo. Por ejemplo, la historia de "soy demasiado bueno" o "soy demasiado blando" - puede ser cierta, puede que no. ¿Cómo llegamos al fondo del asunto? En este caso, lo que hicimos fue que salí a hablar directamente con su equipo.
context: Donna shares her method for helping a CEO who believed negative stories about himself, such as being 'too nice' and that 'nobody listens to him.' She explains how to validate or disprove these self-limiting beliefs by gathering actual feedback from colleagues and team members, similar to conducting user research in product development.
vocabulary_highlights: get down to the bottom of that, went out there

speaker: Donna Lichaw
text: Certain stories we tell ourselves are actually quite functional and do not necessarily need to be rewritten. Imposter syndrome for an example, if you're going around saying, 'I feel like I'm an imposter. I can't believe I'm doing this,' you can try to fake it till you make it, you can try to... but what if you took a counter-intuitive approach and looked at that story, I'm an imposter, and instead asked, 'Okay, that's a good story. How is that serving you?'
text_ko: 우리가 스스로에게 하는 이야기 중에는 실제로 유용한 것들이 많고 꼭 다시 쓸 필요는 없어요. 예를 들어, 임포스터 신드롬(imposter syndrome) 같은 경우, '나는 사기꾼 같아. 내가 이걸 하고 있다니 믿을 수 없어'라고 이야기하면서 다니는 대신, '그 이야기를 반대로 생각해보면, 그게 나에게 어떤 도움이 될까?'라고 물어보는 건 어떨까요?
text_zh: 我们给自己讲的某些故事其实挺管用的，不一定非要改掉。比如说冒充者综合征(imposter syndrome)，如果你老是说"我觉得自己像个骗子，真不敢相信我在做这些事"，你可以试着装到真的为止，也可以试着……但如果你反其道而行之，看看"我是个冒充者"这个故事，然后问问自己："好吧，这故事不错。它对你有什么帮助呢？"
text_es: Hay ciertas historias que nos contamos que en realidad funcionan bastante bien y no necesariamente hay que cambiarlas. Por ejemplo, el síndrome del impostor (imposter syndrome): si andas por ahí diciendo "siento que soy un fraude, no puedo creer que esté haciendo esto", puedes intentar fingir hasta lograrlo, puedes tratar de... pero ¿qué tal si tomas un enfoque contraintuitivo y miras esa historia de "soy un impostor" y mejor te preguntas "okay, esa historia está buena, ¿cómo te está sirviendo?"
context: Lenny asks about imposter syndrome and how to determine if it's a real problem or just a story in your head. Donna offers a counterintuitive approach - instead of trying to eliminate imposter syndrome feelings, examine how they might actually be helping you. She suggests that many negative self-stories serve a functional purpose and can be leveraged positively rather than eliminated.
vocabulary_highlights: fake it till you make it, counter-intuitive approach, how is that serving you

speaker: Donna Lichaw
text: Pull your superpowers out of your stories from your past, your present, and then eventually figure out how to apply them and transpose them to your future. But if you look at your peak experiences from life, from work, but especially from life... if you look at your peak experiences from your past, I would go back to when you were a kid, what's something you did when you were a kid, like a project you worked on or something you were a part of that completely, totally lit you up and that you were so excited about?
text_ko: 과거와 현재의 이야기 속에서 당신만의 슈퍼파워(superpowers)를 꺼내 보고, 그걸 어떻게 미래에 적용해서 옮길지 결국 알아내세요. 그리고 인생에서든 일에서든, 특히 인생에서의 최고의 경험들(peak experiences)을 살펴보면, 저는 어렸을 때로 돌아가 보라고 권하고 싶어요. 어릴 때 했던 일 중에, 직접 해본 프로젝트나 참여했던 활동 가운데 완전히 불이 붙고 정말 신났던 게 뭐였나요?
text_zh: 从你过去和现在的经历中挖掘出你的超能力，然后想办法把它们运用到未来。你仔细想想人生中那些巅峰体验，工作上的也好，生活中的也好，特别是生活中的...回头看看过去那些高光时刻，我建议你回到小时候，想想小时候做过什么事情，参与过什么项目或者活动，让你特别特别兴奋，完全点燃了你的激情？
text_es: Saca tus superpoderes de tus historias del pasado, del presente, y después ve cómo aplicarlos y trasladarlos a tu futuro. Pero si te fijas en tus experiencias más exitosas de la vida, del trabajo, pero sobre todo de la vida... si miras esas experiencias increíbles de tu pasado, yo me iría hasta cuando eras niño, ¿qué es algo que hiciste de pequeño, algún proyecto en el que trabajaste o algo en lo que participaste que te emocionó completamente, que te prendió por dentro y que te tenía súper entusiasmado?
context: Lenny asks how people can identify their superpowers and strengths. Donna explains her method of examining peak experiences throughout your life, especially from childhood, to identify recurring patterns of what energizes and excites you. She prefers this approach over standardized tests because it provides personal context and memorable insights about your natural abilities.
vocabulary_highlights: pull your superpowers out, transpose them, completely, totally lit you up

speaker: Donna Lichaw
text: When superheroes discover what their superpowers actually are, they don't just say, 'Oh, thanks for this gift,' and then run and save the world. Every superhero has a really hard time accepting, 'Oh, this is my gift? Hell no.' Or, 'Wait, what do I do with this?' And they wreak havoc and they make a mess, and it's uncomfortable. And even Superman tries to get rid of his superpowers often because he doesn't like being super.
text_ko: 슈퍼히어로들이 자기 초능력이 뭔지 알게 되면, 그냥 '오, 선물 고마워요' 하고 세상을 구하러 달려가진 않아요. 모든 슈퍼히어로는 '이게 내 선물이야? 절대 안 돼.' 혹은 '잠깐, 이걸로 뭘 해야 하지?'라며 받아들이기 정말 어려워해요. 그래서 난리를 피우고 엉망을 만들고, 상황이 매우 불편해져요. 심지어 슈퍼맨조차 슈퍼인 게 싫어서 종종 초능력을 없애려 해요.
text_zh: 你知道吗，超级英雄刚发现自己有超能力的时候，可不会马上就说"哎呀谢谢老天爷给我这个天赋"，然后就跑去拯救世界了。每个超级英雄一开始都特别难接受，心里想着"搞什么，这就是我的天赋？我靠，不要啊"，或者"等等，我拿这玩意儿干嘛用啊？"然后他们就开始各种折腾，把事情搞得一团糟，特别不适应。就连超人都经常想把自己的超能力给扔掉，因为他根本不想当什么超人。
text_es: Cuando los superhéroes descubren cuáles son realmente sus superpoderes, no es que digan "Ah, qué bueno, gracias por este don" y salgan corriendo a salvar el mundo. Todo superhéroe la pasa muy mal aceptando "¿En serio este es mi don? Ni de broma" o "Espera, ¿y ahora qué hago con esto?" Y la riegan y hacen un desastre, y es súper incómodo. Hasta Superman trata de deshacerse de sus superpoderes seguido porque no le gusta ser súper.
context: Donna uses superhero metaphors to explain why identifying and embracing your strengths can be uncomfortable and challenging. She's responding to a client's discomfort during an experiment about listening in meetings. This analogy helps normalize the difficulty people experience when first recognizing and accepting their natural abilities.
vocabulary_highlights: wreak havoc, make a mess

speaker: Dr. Fei Fei Li
text: I do believe technology is a net positive for humanity, but I think every technology is a double-edged sword. If we're not doing the right thing as a society, as individuals, we can screw this up as well.
text_ko: 저는 기술이 전반적으로 인류에 긍정적(net positive)이라고 믿어요. 그렇지만 모든 기술은 양날의 검(double-edged sword)이에요. 사회로서나 개인으로서 우리가 올바르게 행동하지 않으면, 이걸 망칠 수도 있어요.
text_zh: 我确实觉得科技对人类总体来说是好事，但我认为每项技术都是双刃剑。如果我们作为社会、作为个人没有做对的事情，我们也完全可能把这事儿搞砸。
text_es: Sí creo que la tecnología es algo positivo para la humanidad en general, pero pienso que toda tecnología es un arma de doble filo. Si no hacemos lo correcto como sociedad, como individuos, también podemos cagarla bien feo.
context: Lenny asks Fei-Fei about her perspective on how AI will impact humanity, noting that unlike many AI leaders, she's an optimist who doesn't believe AI will replace humans or take all jobs. Fei-Fei clarifies that she's not utopian about AI's impact - she believes AI's effects depend entirely on human choices and actions. She explains her view that technology generally advances civilization, but emphasizes that humans must act responsibly to avoid negative outcomes.
vocabulary_highlights: net positive, double-edged sword, screw this up

speaker: Dr. Fei Fei Li
text: We need to train machines with as much information as possible on images of objects, but objects are very, very difficult to learn. A single object can have infinite possibilities that is shown on an image. In order to train computers with tens and thousands of object concepts, you really need to show it millions of examples.
text_ko: 우리는 사물 이미지(images of objects)에서 가능한 한 많은 정보를 이용해 기계(machines)를 학습시켜야 해요. 그런데 사물(objects)은 배우기가 정말, 정말 어렵습니다. 같은 사물도 이미지상에서는 무한한 가능성을 가질 수 있어요. 컴퓨터에 수십, 수천 개의 사물 개념(object concepts)을 학습시키려면 실제로 수백만 개의 예시를 보여줘야 해요.
text_zh: 我们得用尽可能多的物体图像信息来训练机器，但物体这东西真的特别难学。就一个物体，在图像上能呈现出无数种可能性。要想让电脑掌握成千上万种物体概念，你真得给它看几百万个样本才行。
text_es: Necesitamos entrenar las máquinas con toda la información posible sobre imágenes de objetos, pero los objetos son súper difíciles de aprender. Un solo objeto puede tener infinitas posibilidades de cómo se ve en una imagen. Para entrenar computadoras con miles y miles de conceptos de objetos, realmente necesitas mostrarles millones de ejemplos.
context: Lenny mentions Fei-Fei's breakthrough insight that machines could think like humans but were missing the vast amount of data that humans naturally acquire as children. Fei-Fei explains her decision to focus AI research on visual intelligence, since humans are deeply visual creatures. She describes the core challenge of object recognition - teaching computers to recognize objects requires enormous amounts of training data because any single object can appear in countless different ways in images.
vocabulary_highlights: infinite possibilities, tens and thousands, object concepts

speaker: Dr. Fei Fei Li
text: I am recognized for being part of the history, but there are so many heroes and so many researchers. We're talking about generations of researchers. In my own world, there are so many people who have inspired me, which I talked about in my book, but I do feel our culture, especially Silicon Valley, tends to assign achievements to a single person.
text_ko: 저는 역사의 한 부분으로 인정받고는 해요. 그런데 정말 많은 영웅들과 수많은 연구자들이 있어요. 연구자들이 세대를 이어 이어온 거죠. 제 분야에도 저에게 영감을 준 분들이 정말 많아서 그 이야기를 제 책에서도 했어요. 다만 우리 문화, 특히 실리콘밸리(Silicon Valley)는 성과를 한 사람에게 귀속시키는 경향이 있는 것 같아요.
text_zh: 大家都说我是历史的一部分，但其实英雄太多了，做研究的人也太多了。我们说的可是好几代研究人员啊。在我自己的圈子里，有太多人给了我启发，我在书里也提到过，但我确实觉得我们这个文化，特别是硅谷(Silicon Valley)，总是喜欢把成就都归到一个人头上。
text_es: Me reconocen por haber sido parte de la historia, pero hay muchísimos héroes y muchísimos investigadores. Estamos hablando de generaciones enteras de investigadores. En mi propio mundo, hay tanta gente que me ha inspirado, de la que hablé en mi libro, pero sí siento que nuestra cultura, especialmente Silicon Valley, tiende a atribuirle los logros a una sola persona.
context: Lenny asks if there's anything else about AI's early history that people should know. Fei-Fei reflects on how she's recognized as being central to AI breakthroughs like ImageNet, but emphasizes the collaborative nature of scientific progress. She points out that AI has 70 years of history involving many generations of researchers, and critiques Silicon Valley's tendency to credit individual 'heroes' rather than acknowledging the collective effort behind major technological advances.
vocabulary_highlights: assign achievements, generations of researchers

speaker: Dr. Fei Fei Li
text: Some tech companies avoid using the word AI because they were not sure if AI was a dirty word. I was actually encouraging everybody to use the word AI because to me that is one of the most audacious question humanity has ever asked in our quest for science and technology, and I feel very proud of this term.
text_ko: 몇몇 테크 기업들은 인공지능(AI)이라는 말을 피했어요. 인공지능이 부정적인 의미로 받아들여질지 확신이 없었기 때문이에요. 저는 오히려 모두가 인공지능(AI)이라는 말을 쓰라고 권했어요. 제게 그 말은 인류가 과학과 기술을 추구해오면서 던져온 가장 대담한 질문들 중 하나로 느껴져요. 그리고 저는 이 용어가 정말 자랑스러워요.
text_zh: 有些科技公司不敢用AI这个词，怕这词儿听起来不太好。但我其实一直鼓励大家大胆用AI这个词，因为在我看来，这是人类在科技探索路上提出的最有野心的问题之一，我为这个词感到特别骄傲。
text_es: Algunas empresas de tecnología evitaban usar la palabra IA porque no estaban seguras si era un término que daba mala imagen. Yo en realidad animaba a todo el mundo a usar la palabra IA porque para mí es una de las preguntas más ambiciosas que la humanidad se ha planteado jamás en nuestra búsqueda del conocimiento científico y tecnológico, y me siento muy orgulloso de este término.
context: Lenny asks about when exactly AI became a widely-used term versus other terms like machine learning. Fei-Fei recalls that as recently as 2015-2016, some technology companies actively avoided calling their work 'AI' because they weren't sure if it was viewed negatively by the public. She explains how she actively encouraged people to embrace the term 'AI' because she saw it as representing one of humanity's most ambitious scientific endeavors.
vocabulary_highlights: dirty word, most audacious question, quest for science and technology

speaker: Dr. Fei Fei Li
text: I'm an intellectually very fearless person, and I have to say when I hire young people, I look for that because I think that's a very important quality if one wants to make a difference. When you want to make a difference, you have to accept that you're creating something new or you're diving into something new.
text_ko: 저는 지적으로 굉장히 두려움이 없는 편이에요. 젊은 인재를 뽑을 때 그런 태도를 중요하게 보는데, 무언가 변화를 만들고 싶다면 그게 정말 중요한 자질이라고 생각해요. 변화를 원한다면 새로운 걸 창조하거나 미지의 영역에 뛰어드는 걸 받아들여야 해요.
text_zh: 我这个人在思维上特别不怕事儿，说实话我招年轻人的时候也专门看这一点，因为我觉得你要是想干出点名堂来，这个品质太重要了。你想要有所作为的话，就得接受这个现实——要么你在创造全新的东西，要么你在往一个全新的领域里扎猛子。
text_es: Soy una persona sin miedo intelectual, y tengo que decir que cuando contrato gente joven, busco exactamente eso porque creo que es una cualidad súper importante si uno quiere marcar la diferencia. Cuando quieres marcar la diferencia, tienes que aceptar que estás creando algo nuevo o te estás metiendo en algo completamente nuevo.
context: Lenny asks what common thread brought Fei-Fei to all the major institutions where AI breakthroughs occurred - SAIL at Stanford, Google Cloud, and now World Labs. Fei-Fei reflects on her career choices and identifies intellectual fearlessness as a key trait that guided her decisions. She explains that making meaningful impact requires courage to venture into uncharted territory, and she actively seeks this quality when hiring at her company.
vocabulary_highlights: intellectually very fearless, diving into something new

speaker: Dr. Fei Fei Li
text: It's so important that even a technologist like me are sincere about that everybody has a role in AI. No technology should take away human dignity and the human dignity and agency should be at the heart of the development, the deployment, as well as the governance of every technology.
text_ko: 저 같은 기술자(technologist)도 누구나 AI에서 역할이 있다는 것에 대해 진심이어야 해요. 어떤 기술도 인간의 존엄성을 빼앗아서는 안 되고, 인간의 존엄성과 자율성(agency)이 모든 기술의 개발과 도입(deployment), 그리고 거버넌스(governance)의 중심에 있어야 해요.
text_zh: 这点真的太重要了，就连我这样搞技术的人都特别认真地认为，每个人在AI这件事上都有自己的角色。任何技术都不应该剥夺人的尊严，人的尊严和主体性应该是每一项技术在开发、部署和治理过程中的核心。
text_es: Es súper importante que incluso alguien de tecnología como yo sea honesto sobre esto: todos tenemos un papel que jugar en la IA. Ninguna tecnología debería quitarle dignidad a las personas, y la dignidad humana y la capacidad de decidir tienen que estar en el centro del desarrollo, la implementación y también de cómo manejamos cualquier tecnología.
context: Fei-Fei addresses a common concern she encounters when traveling - people from various professions asking if they have any role in AI or if AI will simply take over their work. She emphasizes that everyone, from artists to farmers to nurses, has an important role to play in the AI revolution. She stresses that human dignity and agency must remain central to how AI technology is developed, deployed, and governed.
vocabulary_highlights: human dignity and agency, at the heart of

speaker: Drew Houston
text: For the first several years, it was doubling, 10-xing every year. Taping user counts that we printed out to the wall, and then running out of space on the wall. Having to put 100,000 users, 200,000, 500,000, 1,000,000, 10,000,000 on the ceiling.
text_ko: 처음 몇 년 동안은 매년 두 배가 되기도 하고, 어떤 해는 10배씩(10-xing) 늘었어요. 사용자 수를 출력해서 테이프로 벽에 붙여 놨는데, 이젠 벽에 붙일 자리가 없어서 10만명, 20만명, 50만명, 100만명, 1,000만명 같은 숫자들은 결국 천장에 붙여야 했어요.
text_zh: 头几年真是疯狂，每年都翻倍，甚至涨十倍。我们把打印出来的用户数贴在墙上，后来墙都贴不下了。10万用户、20万、50万、100万、1000万，最后只能贴到天花板上去了。
text_es: Durante los primeros años, se duplicaba, se multiplicaba por 10 cada año. Pegábamos en la pared las cifras de usuarios que imprimíamos, y después ya no cabían más en la pared. Tuvimos que poner los números en el techo: 100,000 usuarios, 200,000, 500,000, 1,000,000, 10,000,000.
context: Lenny asks Drew about the early days of Dropbox when things were going extremely well. Drew is describing the incredible growth Dropbox experienced in its first era from 2007 to around 2014. He explains how they would physically print out user milestones and tape them to their office wall to celebrate their rapid user growth, eventually running out of wall space and having to put the numbers on the ceiling as they hit millions of users.
vocabulary_highlights: 10-xing, taping user counts, running out of space

speaker: Drew Houston
text: But weirdly, it was sort of like you see the videos where there's the mushroom cloud in the distance. You see it. But you don't hear, or notice it. It was also clear that winter was coming.
text_ko: 이상하게도, 마치 멀리서 버섯구름이 피어오르는 영상을 보는 것 같았어요. 눈에는 보이는데 소리는 들리지 않고, 별로 실감이 나지 않았어요. 그리고 겨울이 다가오고 있다는 것도 분명했어요.
text_zh: 但很奇怪的是，就像你看那些视频里远处的蘑菇云一样。你能看到，但听不见，也感觉不到什么。而且很明显，寒冬就要来了。
text_es: Pero qué raro, era como cuando ves esos videos donde hay una explosión nuclear a lo lejos. La ves ahí. Pero no escuchas nada, ni te das cuenta del impacto. También estaba clarísimo que se venían tiempos difíciles.
context: Drew is explaining how major tech companies like Apple, Microsoft, and Google started launching competing products around 2011-2012. He uses a vivid metaphor comparing their competitive threats to seeing a distant nuclear explosion - you can see the mushroom cloud but don't immediately feel the impact. The phrase 'winter was coming' refers to Drew sensing that difficult times lay ahead for Dropbox despite not seeing immediate effects in their user numbers.
vocabulary_highlights: mushroom cloud in the distance, winter was coming

speaker: Drew Houston
text: Less than a year later, Google Photos launches. And not only does it provide a lot of the same value, but they also gave you free unlimited storage for life. And so, they just totally nuked our business model.
text_ko: 1년도 채 안 돼서 구글 포토가 나왔어요. 우리가 제공하던 핵심 가치를 많이 그대로 제공했을 뿐만 아니라 평생 무료 무제한 저장공간(unlimited storage)까지 제공했어요. 그래서 그들이 우리 비즈니스 모델을 완전히 무너뜨려 버렸어요.
text_zh: 不到一年，Google Photos就上线了。它不仅提供了差不多同样的价值，还给用户终身免费无限存储。这样一来，我们的商业模式就被彻底干掉了。
text_es: Menos de un año después, Google Photos sale al mercado. Y no solo ofrecía prácticamente el mismo valor, sino que además te daban almacenamiento ilimitado gratis de por vida. O sea, nos volaron completamente el modelo de negocio.
context: Drew is describing a pivotal moment in 2015 when Google launched Google Photos with free unlimited storage, directly competing with Dropbox's Carousel photo-sharing product. This was devastating because Google could afford to give away what Dropbox was trying to monetize.
