Drew uses strong language to emphasize how completely this undermined their strategy - Google didn't just compete, they 'totally nuked' Dropbox's ability to charge for photo storage.
vocabulary_highlights: totally nuked our business model

speaker: Drew Houston
text: So it killed Carousel, killed Mailbox, went all-in on productivity. And I wish I could say, 'Then, everything got better.' It was the opposite, actually. The narrative completely flipped on the company. Suddenly, your employees don't want to wear your T-shirt anymore.
text_ko: 그래서 Carousel 서비스를 접고 Mailbox도 중단하고 생산성에 올인(all-in)했어요. 그리고 ‘그다음에 모든 게 좋아졌어요’라고 말하고 싶지만, 사실은 정반대였어요. 회사에 대한 이야기가 완전히 뒤집혔고, 갑자기 직원들이 더 이상 회사 티셔츠를 입고 싶어 하지 않아요.
text_zh: 所以我们砍掉了Carousel，砍掉了Mailbox，全力押注生产力工具。我多希望能说'然后一切都好起来了'，但实际上恰恰相反。公司的形象完全翻车了。突然间，你的员工都不愿意穿你们公司的T恤了。
text_es: Así que liquidaron Carousel, liquidaron Mailbox, y se volcaron completamente en productividad. Y ojalá pudiera decir 'Y entonces, todo mejoró.' Pero fue todo lo contrario. La narrativa de la empresa cambió por completo. De repente, tus empleados ya no quieren ni ponerse la camiseta de la empresa.
context: Drew is explaining his difficult strategic decision in 2015 to shut down Dropbox's photo-sharing app Carousel and email client Mailbox to focus entirely on workplace productivity tools. Instead of solving their problems, this pivot made things worse - the company's reputation declined dramatically, employee morale plummeted, and even workers became embarrassed to be associated with the Dropbox brand, symbolized by not wanting to wear company merchandise.
vocabulary_highlights: went all-in on, narrative completely flipped, wear your T-shirt

speaker: Drew Houston
text: But I'm very busy, but I'm not really productive. I'm not putting in a lot of creative input. Then the company's not getting a lot of creative output. It just seems like lose, lose, lose all around.
text_ko: 근데 저는 너무 바쁜데 정작 생산성은 높지 않아요. 창의적인 투입(creative input)을 많이 하지 못하고, 그러다 보니 회사도 창의적인 산출(creative output)을 많이 얻지 못해요. 결국 모두에게 손해 보는 상황이에요.
text_zh: 但是我特别忙，可实际上效率很低。我也没有什么创意投入(creative input)。这样公司也得不到什么创意产出(creative output)。感觉就是各方面都在输，没有赢家。
text_es: Pero ando súper ocupado, pero realmente no estoy siendo productivo. No estoy aportando mucha creatividad. Entonces la empresa tampoco está obteniendo resultados creativos. Se ve como que todos perdemos por todos lados.
context: Drew is reflecting on a fundamental problem he identified with modern work culture after COVID. He describes being trapped in a cycle where he was constantly busy with meetings and emails but wasn't actually being productive or creative. This realization led to Dropbox's new mission of designing 'a more enlightened way of working' because Drew recognized that being busy doesn't equal being effective, and this was hurting both individuals and companies.
vocabulary_highlights: lose, lose, lose all around

speaker: Drew Houston
text: You end up fighting wars on three or four fronts against the big kahunas that have infinite cash, and can do whatever they want.
text_ko: 결국엔 자금이 무제한인 거물(big kahunas)들과 세네 군데 전선에서 싸우게 돼요. 그들은 돈이 많아서 하고 싶은 건 다 해버리거든요.
text_zh: 到头来你得同时跟三四个大佬打仗，人家钱多得花不完，想怎么搞就怎么搞。
text_es: Terminas peleando en tres o cuatro frentes contra los peces gordos que tienen dinero ilimitado y pueden hacer lo que se les dé la gana.
context: Drew is describing the strategic challenge Dropbox faced when trying to compete in multiple product areas simultaneously - file storage, photo sharing, productivity tools, and enterprise solutions. Each area put them in direct competition with tech giants like Google, Apple, Microsoft, and Meta. These companies had vastly superior resources and could afford to operate at losses or give away products for free to eliminate competition, making Dropbox's multi-front strategy extremely difficult to sustain.
vocabulary_highlights: big kahunas, infinite cash

speaker: Dylan Field
speaker_expertise: Product Management, User Experience, B2B SaaS
text: I think it's just coming from a place of curiosity, and the more that you can actually understand about underlying work that's being done, the better decisions that you can make, but also the more you can challenge and say, "Okay, is it really going to take this long, and if so, why? Is there something I'm missing?" Oftentimes, there are things I'm missing and things are either harder because we have additional constraints I don't know about in order to get something out and at scale.
text_ko: 그건 단순히 호기심에서 비롯된 것 같아요. 그리고 실제로 진행되고 있는 근본적인 일(underlying work)을 더 잘 이해할수록 더 나은 결정을 내릴 수 있어요. 동시에 "정말 이렇게 오래 걸리는 건가요? 그렇다면 왜죠? 제가 뭔가 놓치고 있는 건 아닐까요?"라고 더 많이 질문하고 도전할 수 있어요. 대개 제가 모르는 추가 제약 때문에 일이 더 복잡해지거나, 결과물을 내고 대규모로 확장하려면(at scale) 더 많은 어려움이 따르기도 해요.
text_zh: 我觉得这主要还是出于好奇心吧，你越是能真正了解底层在做什么工作，你就越能做出更好的决策，同时也能更好地质疑和追问，"真的需要这么长时间吗？如果是的话，为什么？是不是我漏掉了什么？"很多时候，确实是我漏掉了一些东西，而事情之所以更难，是因为我们有一些我不知道的额外限制，这些限制是为了让产品能够推出并且规模化。
text_es: Creo que todo viene de la curiosidad, y mientras más puedas entender realmente el trabajo que se está haciendo por debajo, mejores decisiones vas a poder tomar, pero también más vas a poder cuestionar y decir, "Bueno, ¿en serio va a tomar tanto tiempo, y si es así, por qué? ¿Se me está escapando algo?" Muchas veces sí se me escapan cosas y las cosas son más complicadas porque hay restricciones adicionales que no conozco para poder sacar algo y escalarlo.
context: Lenny asks Dylan about his approach to maintaining startup pace at Figma, specifically how he finds "padding" where teams may be overestimating timelines. Dylan explains his method for questioning project timelines and estimates. He emphasizes coming from a place of genuine curiosity rather than skepticism, and acknowledges that often there are legitimate constraints he wasn't aware of that justify longer timelines.
vocabulary_highlights: coming from a place of curiosity, underlying work, additional constraints, at scale

speaker: Dylan Field
speaker_expertise: Product Management, User Experience, B2B SaaS
text: I think first of all it's like evals are hard. We talked about that earlier. Secondly, the jobs don't just stay the same. They change. Take prompting, and as an engineer there's a range of prompting abilities. The way you discreetize and split up your tasks matters. If you assume that a model can do more than it can do, then you're going to have a bad time.
text_ko: 먼저, 평가(evals)는 어렵다고 생각해요. 그건 아까도 얘기했죠. 둘째로, 업무는 그대로 있지 않고 계속 변해요. 프롬프트 작성(prompting)을 예로 들면 엔지니어마다 프롬프트를 다루는 능력의 범위가 있어요. 작업을 어떻게 분해(discretize)하고 나누느냐가 중요해요. 모델이 실제로 할 수 있는 것보다 더 많은 걸 할 수 있다고 가정하면 곤란해질 거예요.
text_zh: 我觉得首先吧，评估(evals)确实挺难的，这个咱们之前也聊过。其次呢，工作岗位不是一成不变的，会变化。比如说提示工程(prompting)，作为工程师，你的提示能力(prompting abilities)有高有低。你怎么拆解任务、怎么分工，这个很关键。如果你高估了模型的能力，觉得它能做的比实际能做的更多，那你肯定要吃亏。
text_es: Mira, primero que nada, creo que las evaluaciones son complicadas. Ya hablamos de eso antes. Y segundo, los trabajos no se quedan igual, van cambiando. Toma el prompting por ejemplo - como ingeniero hay diferentes niveles de habilidad para hacer prompts. La forma en que divides y organizas tus tareas importa mucho. Si asumes que un modelo puede hacer más de lo que realmente puede, te va a ir mal.
context: Lenny mentions research showing AI approaching human performance on certain jobs and asks about job displacement concerns. Dylan responds by explaining why jobs won't simply disappear even as AI capabilities improve. He argues that evaluating AI performance is difficult and that jobs evolve rather than disappear, using engineering as an example where new skills like effective prompting become important.
vocabulary_highlights: evals are hard, discreetize, you're going to have a bad time

speaker: Dylan Field
speaker_expertise: Product Management, User Experience, B2B SaaS
text: We're no longer in this era of good enough is fine. Good enough is not enough. It's mediocre. If you want to win in the game of software, you need to differentiate through design. Craft matters.
text_ko: 이제 '그냥 괜찮음'으로는 통하지 않아요. '충분히 괜찮다'는 충분하지 않고, 그건 그냥 평범해요. 소프트웨어(software) 분야에서 이기려면 디자인(design)으로 차별화해야 해요. 공들인 완성도, 즉 디테일이 중요해요.
text_zh: 我们已经不在那个"差不多就行"的时代了。差不多根本不够，那就是平庸。如果你想在软件这个赛道上赢，就得靠设计来做差异化。精雕细琢很重要。
text_es: Ya no estamos en esa época donde "está bien así" es suficiente. Lo que está "bien así" ya no alcanza. Eso es mediocridad. Si quieres ganar en el mundo del software, tienes que diferenciarte a través del diseño. La calidad del trabajo importa.
context: Dylan is explaining his vision for how software companies can succeed in today's competitive landscape. He argues that the standards have risen significantly - what used to be acceptable quality is now considered mediocre. His main thesis is that superior design and craftsmanship have become the primary ways to stand out and win in the software industry.
vocabulary_highlights: good enough is fine, win in the game of software, craft matters

speaker: Dylan Field
speaker_expertise: Product Management, User Experience, B2B SaaS
text: About a month before the launch of FigJam at Config, it was like, "Okay, we built a thing." It's just lacking something. The soul isn't there. Let's go differentiate by making FigJam fun. The team was like, "What? We're going to make fun our differentiator?" In retrospect, it was absolutely the right move.
text_ko: 컨피그(Config)에서 피그잼(FigJam)을 런칭하기 한 달쯤 전이었어요. '좋아, 일단 뭔가 만들었네.' 근데 뭔가 부족했어요. 영혼이 없었죠. '피그잼을 재밌게 만들어서 차별화하자'고 했어요. 팀은 '뭐? 재밌게 만드는 걸 우리 차별점으로 삼는다고?'라고 반응했어요. 돌이켜보면 그 결정은 완전히 옳았어요.
text_zh: 在Config大会发布FigJam的前一个月，我们就觉得，"好吧，东西是做出来了。"但总感觉缺了点什么，没有灵魂。后来我们想，要不就让FigJam变得有趣一点，用这个来做差异化。团队当时都懵了，"什么？我们要把'有趣'当作差异化优势？"现在回头看，这个决定绝对是对的。
text_es: Como un mes antes del lanzamiento de FigJam en Config, dijimos "Bueno, ya tenemos el producto armado." Pero le faltaba algo. No tenía alma. Entonces dijimos "Vamos a diferenciarnos haciendo que FigJam sea divertido." El equipo se quedó como "¿En serio? ¿Vamos a hacer que lo divertido sea nuestro diferenciador?" Mirándolo ahora, fue la decisión perfecta.
context: Lenny asks Dylan about counterintuitive decisions he made at Figma. Dylan shares the story of FigJam, their whiteboarding tool, and how a month before launch he realized the product lacked "soul." He made the controversial decision to differentiate the product by making it fun, which the team initially questioned. This decision proved successful and became a defining characteristic of FigJam.
vocabulary_highlights: the soul isn't there, our differentiator, in retrospect

speaker: Dylan Field
speaker_expertise: Product Management, User Experience, B2B SaaS
text: PMs are no longer saying to the designer, "Hey, can you draw this thing out for me?" That frees up designer time to go explore more deeply the stuff they need to go into and it allows anyone to add to that first conversation of, where should we go?
text_ko: 이제 제품 관리자(PMs)들이 디자이너(designer)에게 "이거 대신 그려줄래?"라고 안 말해요. 덕분에 디자이너들은 더 깊이 파고들어야 할 부분을 탐색할 시간이 생기고, 누구나 "우리가 어디로 가야 하지?"라는 첫 대화에 의견을 보탤 수 있게 돼요.
text_zh: 产品经理现在不会再跟设计师说"嘿，你能帮我画个草图吗？"这样设计师就有时间去深挖那些真正需要研究的东西，而且团队里任何人都能参与到"我们应该往哪个方向走"这个最初的讨论中来。
text_es: Los gerentes de producto ya no les dicen a los diseñadores "Oye, ¿me puedes dibujar esto?" Eso libera tiempo del diseñador para que pueda profundizar más en las cosas que realmente necesita investigar, y permite que cualquiera aporte a esa primera conversación de "¿hacia dónde deberíamos ir?"
context: Lenny asks about emerging use cases for Figma Make in AI app prototyping, particularly for product teams. Dylan explains how AI tools are changing the traditional workflow between product managers and designers. Instead of PMs requesting mockups from designers, they can now create prototypes themselves using AI, which allows designers to focus on more complex design challenges while enabling broader participation in early product discussions.
vocabulary_highlights: draw this thing out, frees up designer time, go explore more deeply, first conversation

speaker: Dylan Field
speaker_expertise: Product Management, User Experience, B2B SaaS
text: Have we seen productivity increases? Yeah, but that is not something that has made our new headcount we want for engineering to go down. We're hiring.
text_ko: 생산성은 올랐어요. 다만 그게 엔지니어링(engineering)에서 우리가 확보하려던 신규 인원수(headcount)를 줄일 만큼은 아니에요. 채용은 계속하고 있어요.
text_zh: 生产力有没有提升？确实有，但这并不意味着我们工程团队的招聘计划会因此缩减。我们还在招人。
text_es: ¿Hemos visto aumentos de productividad? Sí, claro, pero eso no significa que vayamos a reducir las contrataciones que queremos hacer en ingeniería. Estamos contratando.
context: Lenny asks which job function might be most threatened by AI automation. Dylan discusses how AI improvements should benefit the entire organization rather than eliminate roles. He acknowledges that Figma has seen productivity gains from AI tools, but explains that this hasn't reduced their desire to hire more engineers - instead, they're continuing to expand their team because there's still so much work to be done.
vocabulary_highlights: productivity increases, new headcount, go down

speaker: Dylan Field
speaker_expertise: Product Management, User Experience, B2B SaaS
text: I think intuition is like a hypothesis generator and you're constantly generating these hypotheses and others are generating hypotheses as well. And you then take these hypotheses and you put them forward and you debate them and you try to find data to support them or negate them. And then you winnow it down into what is our working hypothesis? And from that you move forward.
text_ko: 제 생각엔 직관은 가설 생성기(hypothesis generator) 같아요. 우리는 계속해서 이런 가설을 만들어 내고, 다른 사람들도 마찬가지로 가설을 만들어요. 그 가설들을 제시해서 토론하고, 그것들을 지지할 증거나 반박할 데이터를 찾아보는 거예요. 그런 과정을 통해 추려서 우리의 작업 가설(working hypothesis)이 뭔지 정하고, 그걸 바탕으로 앞으로 나아가는 식이에요.
text_zh: 我觉得直觉就像是个假设生成器，你在不断地产生各种假设，别人也在产生假设。然后你把这些假设拿出来，大家一起讨论辩论，想办法找数据来验证或者推翻它们。最后筛选出我们的工作假设(working hypothesis)，然后基于这个往前推进。
text_es: Creo que la intuición es como un generador de hipótesis, ¿no? Constantemente estás generando estas hipótesis y otros también están generando las suyas. Entonces tomas esas hipótesis, las pones sobre la mesa, las debates y tratas de encontrar datos que las respalden o las refuten. Y después vas descartando hasta llegar a cuál es nuestra hipótesis de trabajo. Y de ahí sigues adelante.
context: Lenny asks Dylan about his superpower of product intuition and taste, comparing him to music producer Rick Rubin who relies on taste rather than technical skills. Dylan explains his framework for how intuition works in product development. He describes intuition not as mystical gut feelings, but as a systematic process of generating ideas that need to be tested and validated through debate and data before becoming actionable strategies.
vocabulary_highlights: hypothesis generator, winnow it down, working hypothesis
topics: Product Management, Decision Making, Strategy & Planning

speaker: Dylan Field
speaker_expertise: Product Management, User Experience, B2B SaaS
text: I ask for examples a lot, I try to ask follow up questions about things and make sure I fully understand it. And I think where I get stuck sometimes is if I ask follow up questions and we don't have answers yet, and then my response might be, 'Let's go find the answer to these questions and then let's go back to this conversation', if I think it's something that's really important.
text_ko: 저는 예시를 자주 부탁하고, 관련해서 추가 질문(follow-up questions)을 해서 완전히 이해하려고 해요. 그런데 가끔 막히는 건 추가 질문을 했는데 아직 답이 없을 때예요. 그럴 땐 그게 정말 중요하다고 생각하면 "이 질문들에 대한 답을 찾아보고 다시 이 대화로 돌아가요"라고 말하곤 해요.
text_zh: 我经常会要求举例子，会追问各种细节，确保自己完全搞明白。我觉得有时候卡住的地方就是，当我追问下去发现大家都没有答案的时候，我可能会说"咱们先去把这些问题的答案找出来，然后再回过头来聊这个话题"，特别是我觉得这个问题很重要的时候。
text_es: Yo pregunto por ejemplos constantemente, trato de hacer preguntas de seguimiento sobre las cosas y asegurarme de que realmente lo entiendo todo. Y creo que donde a veces me quedo atascado es cuando hago estas preguntas de seguimiento y todavía no tenemos las respuestas, entonces mi respuesta suele ser: "Vamos a buscar las respuestas a estas preguntas y después retomamos esta conversación", si creo que es algo realmente importante.
context: Lenny asks Dylan what approaches work best when people try to influence him or change his mind as CEO. Dylan explains his decision-making process, emphasizing that he needs concrete examples and thorough understanding before making important decisions. He describes how he handles situations where teams don't yet have complete information - pausing discussions to gather missing data rather than proceeding with incomplete understanding.
vocabulary_highlights: ask follow up questions, get stuck, go back to this conversation
topics: Leadership & Management, Decision Making, Communication Skills

speaker: Dylan Field
speaker_expertise: Product Management, User Experience, B2B SaaS
text: I think sometimes when you see people that fall down in that function is because they treat it too much like process. Which is very important too, don't me wrong. Good process can help support good outcomes. But I think that you can't lose sight of the problems that you're solving. You have to go talk to users and you have to actually have a strategy. And if you're really good, you should have a point of view.
text_ko: 가끔 그 역할에서 잘 못하는 사람들을 보면, 그 이유가 그걸 지나치게 프로세스(process)처럼만 다루기 때문인 것 같아요. 물론 프로세스도 중요해요, 오해하지 마세요. 좋은 프로세스(process)는 좋은 결과를 뒷받침해 줄 수 있어요. 하지만 해결하려는 문제 자체를 잊으면 안 돼요. 직접 사용자(users)에게 가서 얘기해보고, 실제적인 전략(strategy)을 가져야 해요. 정말 잘하는 사람이라면 자기만의 관점(point of view)을 가지고 있어야 해요.
text_zh: 我觉得有些人在这个职能上栽跟头，就是因为他们太把它当流程来做了。当然流程也很重要，别误会我的意思。好的流程确实能帮你出好结果。但我觉得你不能忘了你到底要解决什么问题。你得去跟用户聊，你得有个真正的策略。如果你真的厉害，你应该有自己的观点和看法。
text_es: Creo que a veces cuando ves gente que falla en esa función es porque lo tratan demasiado como si fuera puro proceso. Lo cual también es muy importante, no me malinterpretes. Un buen proceso puede ayudar a conseguir buenos resultados. Pero pienso que no puedes perder de vista los problemas que estás resolviendo. Tienes que ir a hablar con los usuarios y realmente tienes que tener una estrategia. Y si eres realmente bueno, deberías tener un punto de vista claro.
context: Lenny asks Dylan about the value of product managers at Figma, following Brian Chesky's controversial comments about eliminating PMs at Airbnb. Dylan explains what separates great product managers from those who struggle in the role. He argues that while process management is important, the best PMs focus on solving real problems, engaging with users, developing strategy, and having strong opinions about product direction.
vocabulary_highlights: fall down in that function, don't me wrong, lose sight of, point of view
topics: Product Management, Leadership & Management, Strategy & Planning

speaker: Dylan Field
speaker_expertise: Product Management, User Experience, B2B SaaS
text: The best PMs, I think again, create those frameworks that bring everyone else along and those frameworks also have a point of view and a strategy associated with them. So you're able to take the strategy, take the point of view, wrap it all up in a framework, and then make it so that everyone knows what the destination is and how to get there.
text_ko: 다시 말하면 제 생각엔 최고의 PM(프로덕트 매니저)들은 모두를 함께 이끄는 프레임워크(framework)를 만드는 사람들이에요. 그런 프레임워크에는 분명한 관점(point of view)과 전략(strategy)이 녹아 있고요. 그래서 그 전략과 관점을 하나의 프레임워크로 정리해서 모두가 목적지와 거기까지 가는 방법을 알 수 있게 만드는 거예요.
text_zh: 我觉得最厉害的产品经理(PM)，都会搭建一套框架，让整个团队都能跟上节奏。而且这套框架里面，既有明确的观点，也有配套的策略。你能把战略、观点这些东西都整合到一个框架里，然后让所有人都清楚我们要去哪儿，怎么去。
text_es: Los mejores PMs, yo creo que son los que crean esos marcos de trabajo que logran que todo el equipo vaya en la misma dirección, y esos frameworks también llevan una visión clara y una estrategia bien definida. Entonces puedes tomar la estrategia, tomar esa visión, empaquetarlo todo en un marco de trabajo, y hacer que todos sepan cuál es el destino y cómo llegar ahí.
context: Lenny continues probing about what value the best product managers bring to Figma specifically. Dylan describes the core skill that distinguishes exceptional PMs - their ability to create unifying frameworks. These frameworks don't just organize work, but embed strategic thinking and clear perspectives that help entire teams understand both the end goal and the path to reach it, ensuring everyone is aligned and moving in the same direction.
vocabulary_highlights: bring everyone else along, wrap it all up
topics: Product Management, Leadership & Management, Strategy & Planning

speaker: Dylan Field
speaker_expertise: Product Management, User Experience, B2B SaaS
text: One essay that Evan, my co-founder, introduced me to early on in famous history, I think from Stevie's grants or something like that, contains the term irreducible complexity. And it's basically this idea that one plus one does not equal three, it sometimes equals one and a half. And the more that you add and the more that you continue to put in something, the more complex it gets and the worse it gets.
text_ko: 초기에 공동창업자 에반이 소개해준 에세이 하나가 있는데, 유명한 역사 쪽에서였던 것 같고 스티비의 'grants'였나 뭐였나 기억이 가물가물해요. 그 글에 '환원 불가능한 복잡성(irreducible complexity)'이라는 표현이 나오는데, 기본적으로 1 더하기 1이 항상 3이 되는 게 아니라 때로는 1.5밖에 안 된다는 얘기예요. 더 많이 더하고 계속 뭔가를 집어넣을수록 더 복잡해지고 상황은 더 안 좋아진다는 뜻이에요.
text_zh: 我联合创始人Evan很早就给我看过一篇挺有名的文章，好像是史蒂夫的什么基金报告里的，里面提到一个概念叫"不可简化的复杂性(irreducible complexity)"。大概意思就是说，一加一不一定等于三，有时候反而只等于一点五。你往里面塞的东西越多，继续加的东西越多，整个事情就变得越复杂，效果反而越差。
text_es: Un ensayo que me presentó Evan, mi co-fundador, al principio de nuestra historia conocida, creo que era de las becas de Stevie o algo así, contenía el término complejidad irreducible (irreducible complexity). Y básicamente es esta idea de que uno más uno no siempre es igual a tres, a veces es igual a uno y medio. Y mientras más le agregas y más sigues metiendo cosas, más complejo se vuelve todo y peor queda.
context: Lenny asks Dylan why simplification is so important to him and why it's so difficult to achieve in product development. Dylan references a concept called 'irreducible complexity' that his co-founder Evan shared with him early in Figma's history. He explains this principle using mathematical metaphor - that adding features doesn't create proportional value, and often makes products worse overall due to increased complexity.
vocabulary_highlights: irreducible complexity, one plus one does not equal three

speaker: Dylan Field
speaker_expertise: Product Management, User Experience, B2B SaaS
text: Get it out as fast as you possibly can. Everything they tell you about making sure that you get a product out really quickly is totally true. The faster you get it out, the more feedback you get. That is a positive thing. And now I index on that when we try to build.
text_ko: 가능한 한 빨리 내놓으세요. 제품을 정말 빨리 내놓으라고들 하는 말은 다 맞아요. 빨리 내놓을수록 피드백을 더 많이 받거든요. 그건 긍정적인 일이에요. 그래서 저는 뭔가를 만들 때 그걸 기준으로 삼아요 (index on).
text_zh: 能多快就多快地推出产品。他们说的那些关于要快速推产品的话，完全没错。你推得越快，收到的反馈就越多。这绝对是好事。现在我们在做产品的时候，我就特别看重这一点。
text_es: Sácalo lo más rápido que puedas. Todo lo que te dicen sobre lanzar un producto súper rápido es totalmente cierto. Mientras más rápido lo saques, más feedback vas a recibir. Eso es algo positivo. Y ahora me enfoco en eso cuando tratamos de desarrollar algo.
context: Lenny asks about lessons learned from Figma taking three and a half years to launch initially. Dylan shares his biggest regret about the slow initial launch and what he learned from that experience. He emphasizes that despite taking too long originally, he now prioritizes speed to market because rapid feedback loops are essential for product development, and he applies this principle to current Figma projects.
vocabulary_highlights: index on that
topics: Product Management, Starting a Company, Strategy & Planning

speaker: Dylan Field
speaker_expertise: Product Management, User Experience, B2B SaaS
text: I think that mentors can come from anywhere. It can come from the community, all of you. Mentorship can come from the people you hire. It can come from folks that you actively seek out as investors or explicit mentorship and mentors. It can come from people that call themselves coaches. And what's interesting too is it can come from people you mentor as well.
text_ko: 저는 멘토(mentor)는 어디서든 나올 수 있다고 생각해요. 커뮤니티, 그러니까 여러분에게서도 올 수 있고요. 멘토십(mentorship)은 여러분이 고용한 사람들한테서도 생길 수 있어요. 투자자(investor)나 멘토십을 위해 적극적으로 찾아가는 멘토들에게서도 올 수 있고요. 스스로 코치(coach)라고 부르는 사람들에게서도 배울 수 있어요. 흥미로운 건, 여러분이 멘토하는 사람들에게서도 멘토십이 생길 수 있다는 점이에요.
text_zh: 我觉得导师可以来自各个地方。可能就在你身边的社群里，就是在座的各位。也可能是你招进来的员工。还可能是你主动去找的投资人，或者专门请的导师。有些人叫自己教练(coach)的也行。更有意思的是，有时候你指导的那些人反过来也能当你的老师。
text_es: Creo que los mentores pueden salir de cualquier lado. Pueden venir de la comunidad, de todos ustedes. La mentoría puede llegar de la gente que contratas. Puede venir de personas que buscas activamente como inversionistas o de mentores explícitos. Puede venir de gente que se hace llamar coaches. Y lo interesante también es que puede venir de las personas a las que tú les das mentoría.
context: Lenny asks Dylan what has most helped him scale from being an intern to leading a thousand-person company. Dylan explains his philosophy about learning and mentorship, emphasizing that valuable insights can come from unexpected sources. He describes how mentorship is bidirectional - even people he mentors often teach him new frameworks or perspectives, and that maintaining an open, learning mindset is crucial for leadership growth.
vocabulary_highlights: can come from anywhere, actively seek out, call themselves coaches
topics: Leadership & Management, Learning & Growth, Coaching & Development

speaker: Ebi Atawodi
speaker_expertise: User Experience, Product Strategy, Product Management
text: I think the first piece is that you absolutely need to have one, to start by saying that. Regardless of what level you are in the company. So people say, "Oh, I'm just a junior PM." Whatever level, there is some micro macro vision that you need to have. Because essentially if you got on a plane and the pilot was like, "I don't really know where we're going, but I'm a really good pilot. The company needs to fly 400 flights this year. So I'm trying to make that happen, but trust me, we'll get there."
text_ko: 먼저 가장 중요한 건, 시작할 때 분명히 하나는 있어야 한다고 말하는 거예요. 회사에서 어느 레벨이든 상관없어요. 사람들이 “아, 저는 그냥 주니어 프로덕트 매니저(PM)예요”라고 말하곤 하는데, 레벨과 상관없이 갖춰야 할 마이크로·매크로 비전(micro/macro vision)이 있어요. 본질적으로 비행기를 탔는데 조종사가 “우리가 어디로 가는지는 잘 모르겠지만, 저는 정말 좋은 조종사예요. 회사는 올해 400편을 띄워야 해서 그걸 해내려고 하고 있으니 믿어주세요, 어차피 도착할 거예요”라고 말하는 상황과 같거든요.
text_zh: 我觉得首先一点，你绝对得有愿景，不管你在公司是什么级别。很多人会说"哎呀我就是个初级产品经理(junior PM)"。不管什么级别，你都得有自己的一套大小愿景。为什么这么说呢？你想想，如果你坐飞机，飞行员跟你说"我也不知道要飞哪儿，但我飞机开得特别好。公司今年要飞400个航班，我正努力完成这个目标，相信我，咱们肯定能到的。"
text_es: Creo que lo primero es que definitivamente necesitas tener una, empezando por decir eso. No importa en qué nivel estés en la empresa. La gente dice, "Ay, es que soy nada más un PM junior." Sea cual sea tu nivel, tienes que tener algún tipo de visión, ya sea micro o macro. Porque básicamente si te subes a un avión y el piloto te dice, "La verdad no sé muy bien hacia dónde vamos, pero soy muy buen piloto. La empresa necesita hacer 400 vuelos este año. Entonces estoy tratando de que eso pase, pero confía en mí, vamos a llegar."
context: Lenny asks Ebi about the elements of a good vision for a product or company. Ebi emphasizes that every product manager, regardless of their level, needs to have some form of vision - whether micro or macro. She uses the analogy of getting on a plane where the pilot doesn't know the destination to illustrate why having a clear vision is essential for any PM role.
vocabulary_highlights: micro macro vision, regardless of what level, essentially, trust me, we'll get there
topics: Product Management, Strategy & Planning, Leadership & Management

speaker: Ebi Atawodi
speaker_expertise: User Experience, Product Strategy, Product Management
text: The first one is it needs to be lofty. So it needs to be something that feels... It almost scares you in an exciting way, right? Like, oh, my God, this is something I can get up every morning. And if we did that, goddamn. But at the same time, it needs to be realistic and attainable, so it cannot feel so pie in the sky that it feels so out of reach, right?
text_ko: 첫째는 목표가 웅장해야 해요. 그래서 뭔가 느낌이… 약간 설레면서도 무서울 정도로 와닿는 그런 것이어야 해요. ‘와, 이건 내가 매일 아침 눈 뜨자마자 하고 싶어질 일이다. 우리가 이걸 해낸다면 정말 대박일 거야’라고 느껴지는 거죠. 하지만 동시에 현실적이고 달성 가능해야 해서, 너무 공상적이어서 손에 닿지 않을 것 같은 느낌이면 안 돼요, 그렇죠?
text_zh: 第一个要求就是目标得够远大。得是那种让你既兴奋又有点害怕的感觉，知道吧？就像"我靠，这事儿太牛了，我每天早上都想为这个起床干活。要是真做成了，那就太厉害了。"但同时呢，这目标也得现实一点，得够得着，不能是那种听起来就特别虚的大饼，让人觉得根本没戏，对吧？
text_es: Lo primero es que tiene que ser ambicioso. O sea, tiene que ser algo que se sienta... que casi te dé miedo pero de la buena manera, ¿no? Como que digas "¡madre mía, esto es algo por lo que me puedo levantar cada mañana!" Y si lográramos eso, ¡qué barbaridad! Pero al mismo tiempo, tiene que ser realista y alcanzable, no puede ser algo tan utópico que se sienta inalcanzable, ¿me entiendes?
context: Ebi explains the key elements of a good product vision. She describes how a vision should balance being inspiring and ambitious (lofty) while still feeling achievable. The vision should excite and motivate people to work toward it every day, but not be so unrealistic that it feels impossible to reach.
vocabulary_highlights: lofty, scares you in an exciting way, pie in the sky, out of reach

speaker: Ebi Atawodi
speaker_expertise: User Experience, Product Strategy, Product Management
text: So I have a very simplistic framework. I actually don't know who put it together at Uber, but I see as well, one of the most powerful skills of a product manager is storytelling, right? Because you look at generation after generation after generation, what people pass on as stories, they're not numbers, they're not stats, it's stories.
text_ko: 저는 아주 단순한 프레임워크(framework)가 있어요. 사실 우버에서 누가 정리한 건지는 잘 모르겠는데, 제 생각엔 프로덕트 매니저(product manager)의 가장 강력한 능력 중 하나가 스토리텔링(storytelling)인 것 같아요. 세대가 바뀌어도 사람들이 전하는 건 숫자나 통계가 아니라 결국 이야기거든요.
text_zh: 所以我有个特别简单的框架。其实我也不知道是Uber哪位同事整理的，但我觉得产品经理最厉害的技能之一就是讲故事，对吧？你看一代一代传下来的都是什么？不是数据，不是统计数字，而是故事。
text_es: Entonces tengo un marco súper sencillo. La verdad no sé quién lo armó en Uber, pero yo veo que una de las habilidades más poderosas de un product manager es contar historias, ¿no? Porque si te fijas, generación tras generación, lo que la gente pasa son historias, no números, no estadísticas, sino historias.
context: Lenny asks Ebi about what a vision looks like concretely as a document. Ebi introduces her storytelling framework for creating product visions, emphasizing that storytelling is one of the most powerful skills for product managers. She explains that throughout history, stories have been more memorable and impactful than numbers or statistics for communicating ideas.
vocabulary_highlights: simplistic framework, one of the most powerful skills, generation after generation

speaker: Ebi Atawodi
speaker_expertise: User Experience, Product Strategy, Product Management
text: I think too many people lean into and, "Let's go test it, let's go do some research." It's like, dude, you're a human. Look at the products. Would you use that? You built some intuition from just exposing yourself to really good products. Every time you pick up your phone, what is it about the apps that you love?
text_ko: 사람들이 너무 "테스트해 보자, 리서치하자"에만 매달리는 것 같아요. 근데 진짜 사람이라면 제품을 직접 좀 보세요. 본인이 그걸 쓸 것 같아요? 좋은 제품들을 계속 접하다 보면 자연스럽게 직관(intuition)이 생겨요. 핸드폰을 들 때마다 어떤 점 때문에 그 앱들을 좋아하는지 생각해 보세요.
text_zh: 我觉得太多人就是一味地说"我们去测试一下吧，做点研究"。兄弟，你也是人啊，看看那些产品，你自己会用吗？多接触真正好的产品，你自然就有直觉了。每次拿起手机的时候，想想你爱用的那些app到底好在哪儿？
text_es: Creo que mucha gente se va demasiado por el rollo de "vamos a probarlo, vamos a hacer investigación." Pero oye, eres humano. Mira los productos. ¿Los usarías tú? Ya has desarrollado intuición nada más por exponerte a productos realmente buenos. Cada vez que agarras tu teléfono, ¿qué es lo que te gusta de las apps que más usas?
context: Ebi discusses the 'empathize' step of developing a vision, specifically talking about how product managers should approach understanding user problems. She argues that PMs often over-rely on formal research when they should trust their own intuition as users. She advocates for 'dog-fooding' (using your own product) and 'cat-fooding' (using competitors' products) as essential practices.
vocabulary_highlights: lean into, dude, built some intuition, exposing yourself to

speaker: Ebi Atawodi
speaker_expertise: User Experience, Product Strategy, Product Management
text: If I could put all the research into Bard or ChatGPT and it could spit out a PRD, then you haven't done your job. So basically I maybe panicked my team. I came in, I'm like, gen AI, everybody's talking about all the stuff that you do with creating content, but what I want you to think about is what is the value add you bring that I can't just put into an AI right now and say, "Tell me the big thing based on this research that exists."
text_ko: 만약 제가 모든 연구 결과를 Bard나 ChatGPT에 넣어서 PRD를 뽑아낼 수 있다면, 여러분은 제 역할을 제대로 하지 못한 거예요. 그래서 사실 제가 팀을 좀 놀라게 했던 것 같아요. 제가 들어가서, "요즘 다들 생성 AI에 대해 이야기하는데, 여러분이 제공하는 가치는 뭐냐? 제가 지금 AI에 넣고 '이 연구를 바탕으로 큰 그림을 말해줘'라고 할 수 있는 것 말고요."라고 말했거든요.
text_zh: 如果我把所有的调研都丢给Bard或者ChatGPT，让它直接给我输出一个PRD(产品需求文档)，那说明你们根本就没做好自己的工作。所以我可能把团队给吓着了。我当时就跟大家说，现在大家都在聊生成式AI(gen AI)，都在说它能做各种内容创作，但我希望你们想想的是——你们能带来什么价值是我现在没法直接问AI"基于现有的这些调研，告诉我最重要的发现是什么"就能得到的？
text_es: Si pudiera meter toda la investigación en Bard o ChatGPT y que me escupiera un PRD (product requirements document), entonces no has hecho bien tu trabajo. Básicamente creo que asusté a mi equipo. Llegué y les dije, miren, la IA generativa (gen AI), todo el mundo habla de todo lo que pueden hacer para crear contenido, pero lo que quiero que piensen es cuál es el valor agregado que ustedes aportan que yo no pueda simplemente meter a una IA ahora mismo y decirle "Dime cuál es la gran conclusión basada en esta investigación que ya existe."
context: Lenny and Ebi discuss the importance of product managers developing their own judgment rather than just following research data. Ebi challenges her team to think about what unique value they provide that AI cannot replicate. She emphasizes that if an AI could do a PM's job by simply processing research, then the PM isn't adding sufficient human insight and product sense to their role.
vocabulary_highlights: spit out a PRD, I maybe panicked my team, gen AI, value add

speaker: Ebi Atawodi
speaker_expertise: User Experience, Product Strategy, Product Management
text: I do not believe in being liked. I believe in being loved, right? And that's a very, very different thing. When I said this once in a meeting, people were like... Yes, right? But it took me a while in reading a lot of books to come to a definition of love and love is the choice to extend yourself for the spiritual growth of oneself or another, right?
text_ko: 저는 단순히 '호감'을 얻는 것에는 신경 쓰지 않아요. 저는 사랑받는 걸 더 믿어요, 그렇죠? 그건 완전히 다른 얘기예요. 한 번 회의에서 이렇게 말했더니 사람들 반응이 '아, 맞네' 그런 식이었어요, 그렇죠? 그런데 사랑의 정의에 도달하려고 책을 많이 읽다 보니 시간이 좀 걸렸어요. 제가 내린 사랑의 정의는 '자기 자신이나 다른 사람의 영적 성장(spiritual growth)을 위해 스스로를 내어주기로 선택하는 것'이에요, 그렇죠?
text_zh: 我不相信被人喜欢这件事，我相信的是被人爱，对吧？这完全是两码事。我有一次在会上说了这话，大家都是这个反应...没错吧？但我读了很多书才想明白什么是爱，爱就是你选择让自己付出，为了自己或者别人在精神上能够成长，懂吧？
text_es: No creo en caer bien. Yo creo en que te amen, ¿sí? Y eso es algo muy, muy diferente. Cuando dije esto una vez en una junta, la gente se quedó como... Sí, ¿verdad? Pero me tomó tiempo leyendo muchos libros llegar a una definición del amor, y el amor es la decisión de darte por completo para el crecimiento espiritual de uno mismo o de otra persona, ¿no?
context: Ebi explains her philosophy about team relationships and leadership. She distinguishes between being 'liked' versus being 'loved' in a professional context. She defines love as choosing to extend yourself for someone else's growth, which sometimes means having difficult conversations rather than just being nice or agreeable. This philosophy guides how she approaches feedback and team management.
vocabulary_highlights: I do not believe in, very, very different thing, extend yourself, spiritual growth

speaker: Edwin Chen
speaker_expertise: Data Analytics, Growth Strategy, AI/ML Products
text: We basically never wanted to play the Silicon Valley game. I always thought it was ridiculous. I used to work at a bunch of the big tech companies and I always felt that we could fire 90% of the people and we would move faster because the best people wouldn't have all these distractions. So when we start Surge, we wanted to build it completely differently with a super small, super elite team.
text_ko: 우리는 기본적으로 실리콘밸리 방식(Silicon Valley game)을 따르고 싶지 않았어요. 저는 항상 그게 터무니없다고 생각했어요. 예전에 여러 대형 테크 회사에서 일해봤는데, 직원들 중 90%를 해고해도 괜찮을 것 같다고 느꼈어요. 그러면 핵심 인재들이 이런저런 산만한 일에 방해받지 않아 훨씬 더 빨리 움직일 수 있을 거라고요. 그래서 Surge를 시작할 때는 완전히 다르게 가서, 아주 소수의 초정예 팀으로 만들고 싶었어요.
text_zh: 我们基本上从来就不想玩硅谷那一套。我一直觉得那些都挺扯的。我之前在好几个大科技公司待过，总感觉我们可以裁掉90%的人，反而能跑得更快，因为最牛的那些人就不会被各种乱七八糟的事情分心了。所以我们做Surge的时候，就想完全换个路子，搞一个超小但超精英的团队。
text_es: Básicamente nunca quisimos jugar el juego de Silicon Valley. Siempre me pareció ridículo. Trabajé en un montón de las grandes empresas tecnológicas y siempre sentí que podríamos despedir al 90% de la gente y avanzaríamos más rápido porque la gente más talentosa no tendría todas esas distracciones. Entonces cuando empezamos Surge, quisimos construirlo de manera completamente diferente con un equipo súper pequeño y súper élite.
context: Lenny asks Edwin about Surge's unprecedented achievement of hitting a billion in revenue with only 60-70 people while being completely bootstrapped. Edwin explains why they deliberately chose to avoid the traditional Silicon Valley approach of raising VC money and building large teams. He shares his experience working at big tech companies where he believed most employees were unnecessary distractions that slowed down the best performers.
vocabulary_highlights: play the Silicon Valley game, fire 90% of the people, super elite team

speaker: Edwin Chen
speaker_expertise: Data Analytics, Growth Strategy, AI/ML Products
text: I think most people don't understand what quality even means in this space. They think you could just throw bodies at a problem and get good data and that's completely wrong.
text_ko: 제 생각엔 대부분 사람들이 이 분야에서 '품질(quality)'이 도대체 무슨 뜻인지조차 잘 모르는 것 같아요. 사람만 잔뜩 투입하면 좋은 데이터(data)를 얻을 수 있다고 생각하는데, 그건 완전히 잘못된 생각이에요.
text_zh: 我觉得大部分人根本不懂这个领域里的"质量"到底是什么概念。他们以为随便找一堆人来干活就能搞出好数据，这想法完全是错的。
text_es: Creo que la mayoría de la gente no entiende ni siquiera qué significa calidad en este sector. Piensan que puedes simplemente meter más gente a un problema y obtener buenos datos, y eso está completamente equivocado.
context: Lenny asks Edwin what makes Surge's data quality superior and what others are missing in the AI training data space. Edwin explains that most competitors have a fundamentally flawed understanding of what constitutes high-quality data for AI training. He argues that simply assigning more workers to data creation tasks doesn't improve quality - a common misconception in the industry.
vocabulary_highlights: throw bodies at a problem

speaker: Edwin Chen
speaker_expertise: Data Analytics, Growth Strategy, AI/ML Products
text: I'm worried that instead of building AI that will actually advance us as a species, curing cancer, solving poverty, understand the universe, we are optimizing for AI slop instead. But we're optimizing your models for the types of people who buy tabloids at a grocery store. We're basically teaching our models to chase dopamine instead of truth.
text_ko: 솔직히 걱정돼요. 인류를 진보시키고 암을 치료하고 빈곤을 해결하고 우주를 이해하게 해줄 인공지능(AI)을 만드는 대신에, 우리가 오히려 형편없는 AI(AI slop)을 최적화하고 있는 건 아닌가 싶어요. 문제는 우리가 모델(models)을 식료품점에서 타블로이드(tabloid)를 사는 사람들 같은 타입에 맞춰 최적화하고 있다는 거예요. 결국 모델들을 진실(truth) 대신 도파민(dopamine)을 쫓게 가르치고 있는 셈이에요.
text_zh: 我担心我们现在不是在开发那种真正能推动人类进步的AI，比如攻克癌症、解决贫困问题、探索宇宙奥秘，而是在制造一堆AI垃圾内容。我们现在优化模型的方向，基本上就是迎合那些在超市买八卦小报的人群。说白了，我们是在教模型去追求多巴胺刺激，而不是追求真相。
text_es: Me preocupa que en lugar de crear IA que realmente nos haga avanzar como especie, curando el cáncer, solucionando la pobreza, entendiendo el universo, estemos optimizando para pura basura de IA. Pero estamos optimizando nuestros modelos para el tipo de gente que compra revistas del corazón en el supermercado. Básicamente les estamos enseñando a nuestros modelos a perseguir la dopamina en vez de la verdad.
context: Lenny mentions Edwin's controversial view that AI labs are pushing AGI development in the wrong direction. Edwin expresses concern that instead of focusing AI development on solving humanity's biggest challenges like disease and poverty, the industry is optimizing models for engagement and superficial appeal. He uses the metaphor of tabloid readers to describe how current AI training prioritizes attention-grabbing content over accuracy and meaningful advancement.
vocabulary_highlights: AI slop, chase dopamine instead of truth

speaker: Edwin Chen
speaker_expertise: Data Analytics, Growth Strategy, AI/ML Products
text: So long story short, I think there's all these different factors, and certainly the data is a big part of it, but it's also like what is the objective function that you're trying to optimize your model towards?
text_ko: 간단히 말하면 여러 요인이 있고 데이터가 확실히 큰 부분이긴 한데, 결국 어떤 목적 함수(objective function)를 기준으로 모델(model)을 최적화하느냐가 관건이라고 생각해요.
text_zh: 长话短说吧，我觉得有很多不同的因素在起作用，数据肯定是很重要的一块，但关键还是你想让你的模型朝着什么目标函数(objective function)去优化？
text_es: Bueno, para no hacerte el cuento largo, creo que hay un montón de factores diferentes, y claro que los datos son una parte importante, pero también está el tema de cuál es la función objetivo (objective function) hacia la que estás tratando de optimizar tu modelo, ¿no?
context: Lenny asks Edwin why Claude has been significantly better at coding and writing than other AI models for so long. Edwin explains that a model's superior performance isn't just about data quality, but also depends on the specific goals and values that guide the training process. He describes how different labs make countless choices about what data to include and how to train their models, which creates an almost artistic element in AI development.
vocabulary_highlights: objective function

speaker: Edwin Chen
speaker_expertise: Data Analytics, Growth Strategy, AI/ML Products
text: The easiest way to climb LLM Arena, it's adding crazy boating. It's doubling the number of emojis. It's tripling the length of your model responses, even if your model starts hallucinating and getting the answer completely wrong.
text_ko: LLM 아레나(LLM Arena)에서 순위를 올리는 가장 쉬운 방법은 미친 듯이 과시(boating)를 하는 거예요. 이모지(emojis) 수를 두 배로 늘리고, 모델 응답(model responses) 길이를 세 배로 늘리는 식이죠. 설령 모델이 환각(hallucinating)을 일으켜 답이 완전히 틀려도 괜찮아요.
text_zh: 要在LLM Arena排行榜上爬升，最简单的办法就是疯狂吹牛。把emoji表情符号加倍，把模型回复的长度增加三倍，哪怕你的模型开始出现幻觉(hallucination)，答案完全跑偏了也无所谓。
text_es: La forma más fácil de escalar posiciones en LLM Arena es añadir un montón de palabrería (crazy boating). Es duplicar el número de emojis. Es triplicar la longitud de las respuestas de tu modelo, aunque el modelo empiece a alucinar (hallucinating) y se equivoque completamente en la respuesta.
context: Edwin discusses his concerns about popular AI evaluation platforms like LLM Arena, where random users vote on which AI responses are better. He explains how these platforms create perverse incentives that reward superficial qualities over accuracy. Edwin argues that models can win on these leaderboards by using flashy formatting, excessive emojis, and longer responses that look impressive but may contain completely incorrect information.
vocabulary_highlights: climb LLM Arena, crazy boating

speaker: Edwin Chen
speaker_expertise: Data Analytics, Growth Strategy, AI/ML Products
text: So yeah, I would say don't pivot. Don't put scale. Don't hire that Stanford grad who simply wants to add a hot company to your resume, just build the one thing only you could build, a thing that wouldn't exist without the insight and expertise that only you have.
text_ko: 그러니까 피벗(pivot)하지 마세요. 스케일(scale)에만 매달리지 마시고, 단지 이력서(resume)에 '핫한 회사' 하나 더 올리려고 하는 스탠퍼드 출신 같은 사람은 채용하지 마세요. 그냥 오직 당신만이 만들 수 있는 한 가지를 만드세요 — 당신의 통찰력과 전문성 없이는 아예 존재하지 않았을 그런 것 말이에요.
text_zh: 所以我的建议就是，别轻易转型，别急着扩张规模，也别为了给简历加分就去招那些斯坦福毕业生。就专心做一件事——做只有你能做出来的东西，做那种没有你的独特见解和专业能力就不可能存在的产品。
text_es: Entonces sí, yo diría que no hagas pivot. No te enfoques en escalar. No contrates a ese graduado de Stanford que simplemente quiere agregar una empresa exitosa a su currículum, solo construye esa única cosa que solo tú podrías construir, algo que no existiría sin la perspectiva y experiencia que solo tú tienes.
context: Lenny asks Edwin for his contrarian advice to founders about avoiding the traditional Silicon Valley approach of raising VC money and following standard startup playbooks. Edwin advocates against common Silicon Valley practices like frequent pivoting and rapid scaling. Instead, he encourages founders to focus on building something unique that leverages their specific expertise and insights, rather than following trendy approaches or hiring people who are just seeking prestigious company names for their resumes.
vocabulary_highlights: don't pivot, hot company

speaker: Edwin Chen
speaker_expertise: Data Analytics, Growth Strategy, AI/ML Products
text: If you could choose the perfect model behavior, which model would you want? Do you want a model that says, 'You're absolutely right. There are definitely 20 more ways to improve this email,' and it continues for 50 more iterations or do you want a model that's optimizing for your time and productivity and just says, 'No. You need to stop. Your email's great. Just send it and move on'?
text_ko: 완벽한 모델(model) 행동을 고를 수 있다면 어떤 걸 원하세요? '정말 맞아요. 이 이메일을 더 고칠 방법이 분명히 20가지 더 있어요.'라고 말하면서 50번이나 더 반복(iterations)해서 계속 피드백을 주는 모델(model)을 원하세요, 아니면 당신의 시간과 생산성(productivity)을 최적화하는 모델(model)이 '아니요. 그만하세요. 이메일 충분히 좋아요. 그냥 보내고 다음으로 넘어가요.'라고 딱 잘라 말해 주는 걸 원하세요?
text_zh: 如果让你选择一个完美的模型行为，你会要哪种？你是想要一个模型跟你说"你说得对，这封邮件肯定还有20种改进方法"，然后继续折腾50轮？还是想要一个为你的时间和效率考虑的模型，直接告诉你"别改了，邮件已经很好了，发出去，该干嘛干嘛去"？
text_es: Si pudieras elegir el comportamiento ideal de un modelo, ¿cuál querrías? ¿Quieres un modelo que te diga "Tienes toda la razón. Definitivamente hay 20 formas más de mejorar este email" y que siga así por 50 iteraciones más, o prefieres un modelo que optimice tu tiempo y productividad y que simplemente te diga "No. Para ya. Tu email está perfecto. Solo mándalo y sigue adelante"?
context: Edwin discusses how AI models will become increasingly differentiated based on the values and philosophies of the companies that create them. He shares a personal example of spending 30 minutes with Claude refining an email through multiple iterations, only to realize he had wasted time on something unimportant. Edwin poses a fundamental question about what kind of AI behavior we actually want - one that enables endless perfectionism and consumes our time, or one that prioritizes productivity and helps us move forward efficiently.
vocabulary_highlights: 50 more iterations, move on with your day
topics: Product Management, Decision Making, Work-Life Balance

speaker: Eeke de Milliano
text: Process, by definition, is variance reducing. You're introducing it, because you worry that the variance in your org is too high. You want people to sort of meet a certain standard. And the cost of that is obviously, while you are reducing the standard and bringing folks up to the average, you're also bringing other folks down to the average.
text_ko: 프로세스(process)는 정의상 변동(variance)을 줄이는 거예요. 조직 안의 변동이 너무 크다고 걱정돼서 프로세스를 도입하는 거고, 사람들한테 어느 정도 동일한 기준을 맞추게 하고 싶은 거예요. 그런데 그 대가는 분명해요. 기준을 평준화하다 보면 일부는 평균 수준까지 끌어올리지만, 다른 일부는 반대로 평균으로 끌어내리게 되거든요.
text_zh: 流程嘛，说白了就是为了减少差异性。你之所以要引入流程，是因为担心团队里的表现差距太大，想让大家都达到一定的标准。但这样做的代价很明显，你在把那些表现不好的人拉到平均水平的同时，也把那些本来很优秀的人拖到了平均水平。
text_es: Los procesos, por definición, reducen la variabilidad. Los implementas porque te preocupa que haya demasiada inconsistencia en tu organización. Quieres que la gente cumpla con cierto estándar. Pero el costo es obvio: mientras subes el nivel de algunos y los acercas al promedio, también terminas bajando a otros que estaban por encima de ese promedio.
context: Lenny asks Eeke about finding the right level of process for companies at different stages. Eeke explains her perspective on why process can be problematic - it's designed to reduce variance and create consistency, but this comes at the cost of constraining high performers. She argues that while process brings underperformers up to average, it also brings top performers down to that same average level.
vocabulary_highlights: variance reducing, bringing folks down to the average

speaker: Eeke de Milliano
text: And oftentimes, the folks you're bringing down are your highest performers, your most creative thinkers. The folks who, I think actually don't really need process to do their best work. And so, that, I think is always the tension that you have with process.
text_ko: 그리고 자주 보면, 프로세스(process)를 도입하면서 제약을 받는 사람들은 오히려 성과가 가장 높은 사람들, 가장 창의적인 사람들인 경우가 많아요. 제 생각엔 그분들은 최고의 성과를 내는 데 굳이 프로세스가 필요하지 않은 경우가 많고요. 그래서 그게 프로세스와 늘 생기는 긴장이라고 생각해요.
text_zh: 而且很多时候，你拖累的恰恰是那些表现最好的员工，那些最有创意的人才。我觉得这些人其实根本不需要什么流程就能把工作做得很出色。所以我认为，这就是流程管理永远存在的一个矛盾点。
text_es: Y muchas veces, la gente que terminas frenando son tus mejores elementos, tus pensadores más creativos. La gente que, yo creo, en realidad no necesita procesos para dar lo mejor de sí. Y ahí es donde siempre tienes esa tensión con los procesos.
context: Continuing her discussion about organizational process, Eeke explains who gets hurt most by too much process. She identifies that the people most constrained by process are often the highest performers and most creative thinkers - the very people who don't need process to excel. This creates an inherent tension where the tools meant to help the organization can actually hinder its best talent.
vocabulary_highlights: highest performers, creative thinkers, inherent tension

speaker: Eeke de Milliano
text: I say this often actually, to folks who are thinking about going into product management. 'That's awesome. Just be really, really sure about what you're signing up for.' It's kind of the same as, I think a lot of people want to become a manager. But just so you know, being a manager is like, 'Hey, you're doing performance reviews a lot. And you're in one-on-ones a lot.'
text_ko: 사실 저는 프로덕트 매니지먼트(product management)에 들어가려고 하는 분들에게 이 말을 자주 해요. "정말 멋진 일이에요. 다만 본인이 어떤 일을 맡기로 하는지 정말, 정말 확실히 알고 가세요." 이건 매니저(manager)가 되고 싶어하는 분들에게도 비슷해요. 매니저가 된다는 건 성과 평가(performance reviews)를 자주 하고, 1:1 미팅(one-on-ones)을 자주 한다는 뜻이에요.
text_zh: 我其实经常跟那些想转产品经理(product management)的人这么说："这想法挺好的，但你得非常非常清楚自己要面对什么。" 这就像很多人都想当管理者一样。但你要知道，当管理者就意味着你得经常做绩效评估，经常要和下属一对一谈话(one-on-one)。
text_es: La verdad es que digo esto bastante seguido, a la gente que está pensando en meterse en gestión de productos. 'Qué bueno, pero asegúrate muy, muy bien de en qué te estás metiendo.' Es medio lo mismo que pasa, creo que mucha gente quiere convertirse en manager. Pero para que sepas, ser manager es como que 'Oye, vas a estar haciendo evaluaciones de desempeño todo el tiempo. Y vas a vivir en reuniones uno a uno.'
context: Lenny and Eeke discuss why companies like Stripe were initially hesitant to hire product managers, with engineers preferring to do product work themselves. Eeke warns people considering product management careers about the reality of the role. She compares it to management, where people are attracted to the perceived authority and influence but don't realize much of the actual work involves less glamorous tasks like performance reviews and one-on-ones.
vocabulary_highlights: signing up for, performance reviews, one-on-ones

speaker: Eeke de Milliano
text: And I very strongly believe this. I don't think you can be a good writer, unless you're a clear thinker. And if you couldn't write well, I think it was actually pretty hard to be successful at Stripe, at least in the early days. So I think Stripe just cultivated a lot of really good writers, and by input into that, a lot of really good thinkers.
text_ko: 저는 이걸 정말 강하게 믿어요. 생각이 명확하지 않으면 좋은 글을 쓸 수 없다고 생각해요. 적어도 초창기에는 글을 잘 못 쓰면 Stripe에서 성공하기가 사실 꽤 어려웠던 것 같아요. 그래서 Stripe는 글을 잘 쓰는 사람들을 많이 길러냈고, 그 덕분에 사고력이 뛰어난 사람들도 많이 배출됐다고 생각해요.
text_zh: 我对这点深信不疑。我觉得如果你思路不清晰的话，是写不出好文章的。在Stripe，特别是早期的时候，如果你文笔不行，说实话很难混得好。所以Stripe就培养了一大批特别会写的人，换句话说，也就是培养了一大批脑子特别好使的人。
text_es: Y esto lo tengo clarísimo. No creo que puedas ser buen escritor si no tienes las ideas claras. Y si no sabías escribir bien, la verdad es que era bastante difícil triunfar en Stripe, al menos en los primeros años. Entonces creo que Stripe cultivó muchísimos escritores excelentes, y como consecuencia de eso, muchísimos pensadores excelentes.
context: Lenny asks Eeke what made Stripe's culture unique and successful. Eeke explains Stripe's strong writing culture, where all important communication happened through written documents like business reviews and strategy memos. She argues that good writing and clear thinking are inseparable skills, and Stripe's emphasis on writing quality effectively selected for and developed clear thinkers throughout the organization.
vocabulary_highlights: cultivated, by input into that

speaker: Eeke de Milliano
text: I always wonder, 'What is it that's stopping folks from being creative and thinking bigger?' And I think it comes down to a couple of things that companies do sort of unwillingly, or not even realizing it. And one is this fear of failure. I think leaders want the upside of innovation, but they're not really willing to deal with the cost of innovation.
text_ko: 저는 늘 '무엇이 사람들로 하여금 창의적으로 생각하거나 더 크게 생각하지 못하게 할까?' 하고 궁금해해요. 제 생각엔 그건 회사들이 의도치 않게, 혹은 자기도 모르게 하는 몇 가지 때문인 것 같아요. 그중 하나가 실패에 대한 두려움(fear of failure)이에요. 리더들은 혁신(innovation)의 성과는 원하지만, 혁신에 드는 비용(cost)은 감수하려 하지 않는 경우가 많아요.
text_zh: 我一直在想，"到底是什么阻碍了大家发挥创意、把格局做大呢？"我觉得归根结底是公司在不知不觉中做的几件事，或者说根本没意识到在做。其中一个就是害怕失败。我觉得领导们都想要创新带来的好处，但他们其实不太愿意承担创新的代价。
text_es: Siempre me pregunto: "¿Qué es lo que frena a la gente para ser creativa y pensar en grande?" Y creo que se reduce a un par de cosas que las empresas hacen medio sin querer, o sin darse cuenta siquiera. Una es este miedo al fracaso. Creo que los líderes quieren los beneficios de la innovación, pero realmente no están dispuestos a pagar el precio que conlleva innovar.
context: Lenny asks why some teams can innovate consistently while others stay conservative. Rather than focusing on what makes teams innovative, Eeke examines what prevents innovation. She identifies fear of failure as a key barrier, explaining that leaders often want the benefits of innovation but aren't prepared to accept that big swings inevitably lead to some failures. This creates an environment where people avoid taking creative risks.
vocabulary_highlights: thinking bigger, upside of innovation, deal with the cost

speaker: Eeke de Milliano
text: To me, the unlock for organizations is managers, for this. Because you need managers to both detect the high performers and be like, 'This person doesn't need the process.' And then you need managers to give that person air cover to be like, 'We're honestly...' Because what you're doing is, you're giving them some special treatment and you need to be kind of okay with that.
text_ko: 제게는 이걸 조직에서 푸는 열쇠는 관리자들이에요. 관리자는 고성과자(high performers)를 찾아내서 '이 사람은 이 프로세스(process)가 필요 없어요'라고 판단할 수 있어야 해요. 그리고 그런 사람에게는 관리자가 에어커버(air cover)를 제공해서 '솔직히...'라고 말할 수 있도록 보호해 줘야 해요. 결국 그들에게 약간의 특별 대우를 해주는 건데, 조직이 그걸 어느 정도 받아들일 수 있어야 해요.
text_zh: 我觉得对于企业来说，关键就是看管理者怎么做。因为你需要管理者既能发现那些高绩效的人，然后说"这人不需要按流程来"。同时管理者还得给这个人撑腰，因为说白了，你就是在给他们开绿灯，搞特殊化，你得接受这一点。
text_es: Para mí, la clave para las organizaciones son los gerentes, en este tema. Porque necesitas que los gerentes identifiquen a los que más rinden y digan, "Esta persona no necesita seguir el proceso al pie de la letra." Y luego necesitas que los gerentes les den cobertura, tipo, "Mira, la cosa es que..." Porque lo que estás haciendo es darles un trato especial y tienes que estar bien con eso.
context: Lenny asks how to create escape hatches for top performers who are constrained by organizational processes. Eeke explains that managers are the key to solving this problem. Managers must be able to identify high performers who don't need standard processes, then provide 'air cover' - protection from organizational scrutiny - when giving these individuals special treatment and flexibility to work outside normal procedures.
vocabulary_highlights: the unlock, air cover, special treatment

speaker: Eeke de Milliano
text: I have a couple of, I guess, specific mental models that I use. The first is, build for your best user, not your worst user. And what I mean by that is, I think it's actually really easy to get stuck, or to focus on, 'What if there's abuse of this product?' Or think about all the ways in which the product won't be used well.
text_ko: 저는 개인적으로 몇 가지 구체적인 멘탈 모델(mental models)을 써요. 첫째는, 제품은 최악의 사용자 대신 최고의 사용자를 위해 만들어야 해요. 그 말은, 사람들이 쉽게 '이 제품이 악용되면 어떡하지?'에 집착하거나 제품이 제대로 쓰이지 않을 온갖 경우만 생각하느라 막혀버리기 쉽다는 뜻이에요.
text_zh: 我有几个比较具体的思维模式吧。第一个就是，为你最好的用户去做产品，而不是为最差的用户。我的意思是，其实很容易就陷入一个误区，老是想着"万一有人滥用这个产品怎么办？"或者总是考虑产品可能被误用的各种情况。
text_es: Tengo un par de modelos mentales específicos que uso. El primero es: construye para tu mejor usuario, no para el peor. Y con esto me refiero a que es súper fácil quedarte atascado pensando en "¿Y si abusan de este producto?" O ponerte a darle vueltas a todas las formas en que el producto no se va a usar bien.
context: Lenny asks Eeke about product building philosophies she's found useful. Eeke shares her first mental model about user focus. She argues that teams often get distracted by edge cases and potential product abuse, then end up designing awkward features to prevent misuse. Instead, she advocates focusing on the ideal users who will use the product correctly, since poor users should represent only a small fraction of the user base.
vocabulary_highlights: mental models, build for your best user, abuse of this product

speaker: Elena Verna
text: Product-led growth has actually started more on individual use case, so an individual has a problem. They have a job to be done. They come into the product and they solve it, and that was product-led growth in a nutshell for a lot of the B2B companies. However, if you're going to attach a salesperson, there is nobody in the company that is going to pay 10, 15, $20,000 for one individual to solve their problem.
text_ko: 제품 주도 성장(product-led growth)은 사실 개인의 사용 사례에서 시작된 경우가 많아요. 개인이 문제를 가지고 있고, 해결해야 할 일이 있죠. 그들이 제품에 들어와서 그 문제를 해결하면, 이게 많은 B2B 회사에서의 제품 주도 성장의 핵심이에요. 하지만 만약 영업사원을 붙이게 되면, 회사에서 한 개인이 문제를 해결하는 데 1만, 1만5천, 2만 달러를 지불할 사람은 없어요.
text_zh: 产品驱动增长(product-led growth)其实一开始都是从个人用户的具体需求出发的，就是某个人遇到了问题，需要完成某项工作，然后他们用你的产品解决了这个问题，这就是很多B2B公司产品驱动增长的核心逻辑。但是呢，如果你要配销售人员的话，公司里没人会为了解决一个员工的个人问题就花个一两万、甚至两三万美金的。
text_es: El crecimiento impulsado por producto (product-led growth) en realidad empezó más con casos de uso individuales, o sea, una persona tiene un problema específico. Tiene una tarea que resolver (job to be done). Entra al producto, lo resuelve, y eso era el crecimiento impulsado por producto en pocas palabras para muchas empresas B2B. Pero si vas a meter a un vendedor en la ecuación, no hay nadie en la empresa que vaya a pagar 10, 15 o 20 mil dólares para que una sola persona resuelva su problemita.
context: Lenny asks whether product-led sales is a new trend or if it has always been part of product-led growth. Elena explains the evolution from traditional product-led growth, which focused on individuals solving personal problems through self-serve products, to product-led sales, which requires scaling beyond individual use cases to justify enterprise-level sales involvement and higher contract values.
vocabulary_highlights: in a nutshell, attach a salesperson, job to be done
topics: Product Management, Growth & Marketing, Strategy & Planning

speaker: Elena Verna
text: Product-led sales assumes that there is a migration from an individual use case that you acquired an end user with and an escalation into an enterprise-level solution that solves enterprise-level problems. Individual is not solving for data-driven culture. Individual is just solving for data insights for them. Company's solving for data-driven culture.
text_ko: 제품 주도 영업(product-led sales)은 개별 사용 사례(individual use case)로 확보한 최종 사용자(end user)가 점차 기업용 솔루션(enterprise-level solution)으로 확장되며 기업 차원의 문제를 해결하게 된다는 가정이에요. 개인 수준에서는 데이터 기반 문화(data-driven culture)를 만드는 게 목표가 아니에요. 개인은 그저 자신에게 필요한 데이터 인사이트(data insights)를 얻는 것이고, 회사는 데이터 기반 문화를 구축하려고 해요.
text_zh: 产品驱动销售(product-led sales)有个基本假设，就是用户会从个人使用场景慢慢升级到企业级解决方案，去解决企业层面的问题。个人用户关注的不是什么数据驱动文化(data-driven culture)，他们就是想要对自己有用的数据洞察(data insights)。但公司考虑的是整个数据驱动文化的建设。
text_es: Las ventas impulsadas por producto (product-led sales) asumen que hay una migración desde un caso de uso individual con el que captaste al usuario final hacia una escalación a una solución a nivel empresarial que resuelve problemas empresariales. El individuo no está buscando crear una cultura basada en datos. El individuo solo está resolviendo sus propias necesidades de insights de datos. La empresa está resolviendo el tema de crear una cultura basada en datos.
context: Elena uses Amplitude as an example to illustrate the difference between individual and enterprise-level problems. She explains how product-led sales bridges the gap between what individuals need (personal data insights) versus what companies need (organization-wide data-driven culture), demonstrating why sales involvement becomes necessary for larger contracts.
vocabulary_highlights: migration from, escalation into, enterprise-level solution
topics: Product Management, Growth & Marketing, Strategy & Planning

speaker: Elena Verna
text: Sales can tell that story. Sales can bridge that gap, and then you can increase the perceived value in order to bridge the gap to that $15,000, 20, hundred-thousand dollar contract. I would say self-serve monetization is very much an individual use case versus product-led sales is turning that individual use case and self-serve usage into a sales pipeline with enterprise-level value.
text_ko: 영업팀이 그 이야기를 전할 수 있어요. 영업이 그 간극을 메워주고, 인지된 가치를 끌어올려서 $15,000, $20,000, $100,000짜리 계약까지 이어가게 할 수 있어요. 저는 셀프 서비스 수익화(self-serve monetization)는 주로 개별 사용 사례에 가깝고, 제품 주도 영업(product-led sales)은 그 개별 사용 사례와 셀프 서비스 이용을 영업 파이프라인(sales pipeline)으로 전환해 엔터프라이즈급 가치(enterprise-level value)를 만들어내는 접근이라고 생각해요.
text_zh: 销售团队能讲好这个故事，能够填补这个空缺，然后你就可以提升客户感知价值，这样就能拿下1万5、2万，甚至几十万美金的大单。我觉得自助式变现(self-serve monetization)主要针对的是个人用户场景，而产品驱动销售(product-led sales)就是把这些个人用户场景和自助使用转化成销售管道(sales pipeline)，创造企业级的价值。
text_es: Ventas puede contar esa historia. Ventas puede cerrar esa brecha, y entonces puedes aumentar el valor percibido para llegar a ese contrato de 15 mil, 20 mil, o hasta cien mil dólares. Yo diría que la monetización de autoservicio (self-serve monetization) es más bien para casos de uso individuales, mientras que las ventas dirigidas por producto (product-led sales) es tomar ese caso de uso individual y ese uso de autoservicio y convertirlo en un pipeline de ventas con valor a nivel empresarial.
context: Elena explains why sales teams are essential in product-led sales motions. She describes how products excel at demonstrating individual user value but struggle to communicate enterprise-level benefits, while sales teams can effectively articulate organizational value propositions to justify much larger contract values than what self-serve models typically achieve.
vocabulary_highlights: bridge the gap, perceived value, sales pipeline
topics: Product Management, Growth & Marketing, Leadership & Management

speaker: Elena Verna
text: That organic demand very quickly dries up if you rely on hand-raisers of your champions. If you rely on having enterprise buyers in your user base that are asking to just sign on the dotted line, then you have a very limited ceiling for your growth because what majority of the usage transforms to be is to have product qualification that there's a meaningful sales conversation that could occur based on the signals within usage that the buyer is missing.
text_ko: 그 유기적 수요(organic demand)는 챔피언(champions)들 가운데 자발적으로 손을 드는 사람들(hand-raisers)에만 의존하면 금세 말라버려요. 사용자 기반에 있는 엔터프라이즈 구매자(enterprise buyers)들이 그냥 도장 찍고 서명만 하길 바라는 식으로 의존하면 성장의 한계가 아주 낮아요. 그 이유는 대부분의 사용이 구매자가 놓치고 있는 사용 내 신호(signals)를 바탕으로 영업 대화가 성립할 만한지 판단하는 제품 적합성(product qualification)으로 바뀌기 때문이에요.
text_zh: 如果你只是坐等那些支持你的人主动举手，或者只指望用户群里的企业买家主动要求签合同，那这种自然需求很快就会枯竭。这样做的话，你的增长天花板会很低，因为大部分使用情况最终都需要做产品验证(product qualification)，需要根据使用数据里的信号来判断买家可能忽略的地方，这样才能开展有意义的销售对话。
text_es: Esa demanda orgánica se seca muy rápido si te basas solo en que tus usuarios más entusiastas levanten la mano. Si dependes de tener compradores corporates en tu base de usuarios que simplemente quieran firmar el contrato, entonces tienes un techo de crecimiento muy limitado, porque lo que pasa con la mayoría del uso es que necesitas una calificación del producto (product qualification) para que pueda haber una conversación de ventas que valga la pena, basada en las señales de uso que el comprador no está viendo.
context: Lenny asks about the bridge between product and sales in product-led sales motions. Elena explains that while companies often start with organic demand from users requesting enterprise purchases, this approach has limitations. Most successful product-led sales requires proactive identification of qualified accounts based on usage patterns, since end users typically aren't the enterprise buyers.
vocabulary_highlights: dries up, hand-raisers, sign on the dotted line, limited ceiling
topics: Growth & Marketing, Strategy & Planning, Decision Making

speaker: Elena Verna
text: To have product-led sales means you're going upmarket, period. That means you going for contract values that are probably over your sales floor, so the minimum that the sales is willing to engage and close, which is traditionally around $15,000. If you're going for contract values of $15,000, that means you're probably trying to close a hundred, $200,000 contracts as well.
text_ko: 제품 주도 영업(product-led sales)을 한다는 건 결국 업마켓(upmarket)으로 간다는 뜻이에요. 즉 전통적으로 영업팀이 기꺼이 개입해서 성사시키는 최소 수준, 이른바 '영업 최저선'(sales floor)인 약 $15,000를 넘는 계약 규모(contract values)를 노리게 된다는 말이에요. 그리고 최소선이 $15,000라면 보통 $100,000~$200,000짜리 계약도 함께 성사시키려는 경우가 많아요.
text_zh: 做产品驱动销售(product-led sales)就意味着你要往高端市场走，这是必然的。也就是说你要去争取那些超过你销售底线的合同金额，就是销售团队愿意跟进和成交的最低金额，传统上大概是1万5千美金左右。如果你的目标合同金额是1万5千美金的话，那说明你可能同时也在努力拿下10万、20万美金的大单子。
text_es: Tener ventas orientadas por el producto significa que vas hacia mercados más grandes, punto. Eso significa que vas por contratos que probablemente están por encima de tu piso de ventas (sales floor), o sea, lo mínimo que el equipo de ventas está dispuesto a trabajar y cerrar, que tradicionalmente anda por los $15,000 dólares. Si estás buscando contratos de $15,000, eso significa que probablemente también estás tratando de cerrar contratos de cien mil, $200,000 dólares.
context: Lenny asks what signs indicate a product is fit for investing in product-led sales. Elena explains that product-led sales inherently means moving upmarket to enterprise customers, as it requires contract values that justify sales team involvement - typically $15,000 minimum but often $100,000-200,000 contracts, which only larger companies with 200+ or 1,000+ employees can handle.
vocabulary_highlights: going upmarket, sales floor, contract values
topics: Strategy & Planning, Growth & Marketing, Decision Making

speaker: Elena Verna
text: We've alleviated our product management in B2B from monetization ownership. When a SLG company actually goes into product-assisted tactics or product-led growth, the biggest pain point is actually educating product team on how can you get product to sell itself, which is all about monetization awareness, monetization friction of conversion to get into the paid plan, and then having actual correct value metrics that are understood self-serve by the customer.
text_ko: 우리는 B2B에서 제품 관리의 수익화 책임을 덜어냈어요. SLG 회사가 제품 중심의 전략이나 제품 주도 성장(product-led growth)을 시도할 때 가장 큰 문제는 제품 팀에게 제품이 스스로 판매될 수 있는 방법을 교육하는 거예요. 이건 수익화 인식과 유료 플랜으로 전환하는 데 필요한 수익화 마찰에 관한 것이고, 고객이 스스로 이해할 수 있는 올바른 가치 지표를 갖추는 것도 중요해요.
text_zh: 我们把B2B产品管理从变现责任中解放出来了。当一个销售主导(SLG)的公司真正开始用产品辅助策略或者产品驱动增长(PLG)的时候，最大的痛点其实是教会产品团队怎么让产品自己会卖货，这主要涉及三个方面：变现意识、付费转化时的摩擦问题，还有让客户能够自助理解的正确价值指标。
text_es: Hemos liberado a nuestro equipo de producto en B2B de tener que encargarse directamente de la monetización. Cuando una empresa SLG realmente se mete en tácticas asistidas por producto o crecimiento liderado por producto (product-led growth), el mayor dolor de cabeza es en realidad educar al equipo de producto sobre cómo lograr que el producto se venda solo, lo cual tiene que ver con crear conciencia sobre la monetización, reducir la fricción en la conversión para que pasen al plan de pago, y después tener métricas de valor correctas que el cliente pueda entender por sí mismo de manera autoservicio.
context: Elena discusses how sales-led growth companies have historically separated product teams from revenue responsibility. She explains that when these companies try to add product-led elements, the main challenge is teaching product teams to own monetization - including making customers aware of paid features, reducing conversion friction, and creating clear value metrics that customers can understand without sales assistance.
vocabulary_highlights: alleviated, monetization ownership, monetization friction, value metrics
topics: Product Management, Leadership & Management, Strategy & Planning

speaker: Elena Verna
text: The most important thing in product-led sales is that there is a different configuration internally of collaboration that needs to occur. In traditional sales world, marketing creates pipeline for sales. Sales sells product. Product engages with a paid user to drive retention. In the product-led sales, product acquires and activates a customer and product creates pipeline for sales, so relationship is not that there's a go-to-market org with marketing and sales and product just kind of throws features across the fence for them to sell.
text_ko: 제품 주도형 영업(product-led sales)에서 가장 중요한 건 내부적으로 협업 방식이 달라져야 한다는 점이에요. 전통적인 영업 환경에서는 마케팅이 세일즈를 위한 파이프라인(pipeline)을 만들고, 세일즈가 제품을 팔고, 제품팀은 유료 사용자(paid user)를 케어해 유지(retention)를 높이는 역할을 해요. 반면 제품 주도형 영업에서는 제품이 고객을 획득하고 활성화시키며, 제품이 세일즈를 위한 파이프라인(pipeline)을 만들어요. 즉, 마케팅과 세일즈로 구성된 go-to-market(go-to-market) 조직이 있고 제품은 그냥 기능만 넘겨주면 그들이 알아서 파는 그런 관계가 아니에요.
text_zh: 产品驱动销售(product-led sales)最关键的一点是，内部协作的配置跟传统模式完全不一样。传统销售模式下，市场部负责给销售部输送潜客，销售部负责卖产品，产品部负责跟付费用户打交道来提高留存率。但在产品驱动销售模式里，是产品部门来获客和激活客户，产品给销售部创造销售线索。所以这种关系不是说有个市场销售部门(go-to-market org)，然后产品部就在那儿闷头做功能，做完了扔给他们去卖。
text_es: Lo más importante en las ventas impulsadas por producto (product-led sales) es que internamente necesitas una configuración de colaboración completamente diferente. En el mundo de ventas tradicional, marketing crea el pipeline para ventas. Ventas vende el producto. Producto trabaja con usuarios pagos para impulsar la retención. En las ventas impulsadas por producto (product-led sales), el producto adquiere y activa al cliente y el producto crea el pipeline para ventas, entonces la relación ya no es que tengas una organización de go-to-market con marketing y ventas donde producto simplemente les lanza funcionalidades por encima del muro para que las vendan.
context: Elena explains the fundamental organizational changes required for successful product-led sales implementation. She contrasts the traditional sales model where marketing feeds sales and product only engages post-purchase, with product-led sales where product teams must take accountability for both customer acquisition and pipeline creation, requiring much closer collaboration between product and sales teams.
vocabulary_highlights: configuration internally, throws features across the fence, go-to-market org
topics: Leadership & Management, Strategy & Planning, Product Management

speaker: Elena Verna
text: We live in tech. There's always lots of startups and startups obviously looking to grow. There is a huge misconception in the field that in order to get growth going, you need a growth team. To figure out your product market fit and how to distribute it, it's not something that you can outsource to somebody.
text_ko: 우리는 테크(tech) 업계에서 살고 있어요. 항상 스타트업(startups)이 많고, 스타트업들은 당연히 성장하려고 해요. 그런데 업계에는 성장을 위해 그로스 팀(growth team)이 꼭 필요하다는 큰 오해가 있어요. 제품-시장 적합성(product-market fit)을 찾아서 그걸 어떻게 배포(distribution)할지는 다른 사람에게 아웃소싱(outsource)할 수 있는 일이 아니에요.
text_zh: 我们就在科技圈里混，到处都是初创公司，而且都想着要做大做强。但是这个行业有个特别大的误区，就是觉得想要实现增长，就得搞个增长团队(growth team)。但其实要搞清楚你的产品市场匹配度(product market fit)，还有怎么去推广分发，这些事儿你是没法外包给别人的。
text_es: Nosotros vivimos en el mundo tech. Siempre hay un montón de startups y obviamente todas buscan crecer. Hay un malentendido enorme en el sector de que para empezar a crecer necesitas un equipo de crecimiento (growth team). Para descifrar tu product market fit y cómo distribuirlo, eso no es algo que puedas tercerizar o delegar a alguien más.
context: Lenny asks Elena about growth tactics that never work, starting with the first item on her list. Elena explains one of the biggest hiring mistakes she sees in the growth field - companies hiring growth teams too early. She argues that achieving product-market fit and learning how to distribute your product requires founder-led effort rather than outsourcing to a specialized team.
vocabulary_highlights: huge misconception, outsource to somebody

speaker: Elena Verna
text: Never ever once have I seen a rebrand or redesign, especially of UK marketing site produce good performance results. New CMO comes in designing their website or designing the brand as if it was reflection of their personal taste, and oftentimes it's promised with our acquisition is going to go up and it never materializes into anything meaningful.
text_ko: 저는 리브랜딩(rebrand)이나 리디자인(redesign), 특히 영국 마케팅 사이트(marketing site) 쪽에서 좋은 성과를 낸 걸 한 번도 본 적이 없어요. 새로 오는 CMO(최고마케팅책임자)들은 자기 개인 취향을 반영하듯 웹사이트나 브랜드를 손대고, '고객 획득(acquisition)이 늘어날 거예요'라고 약속하곤 하는데 실제로는 의미 있는 결과로 이어지는 경우가 거의 없어요.
text_zh: 我从来没见过重新做品牌或者redesign网站，特别是英国那些营销网站，能真正带来好效果的。新来的CMO总是按照自己的喜好来搞网站设计或者品牌形象，嘴上说什么客户获取会大幅提升，结果每次都是雷声大雨点小，根本没什么实际效果。
text_es: Nunca, pero nunca he visto que un cambio de marca o rediseño, especialmente de sitios web de marketing en Reino Unido, dé buenos resultados de rendimiento. Llega un CMO nuevo y se pone a diseñar su sitio web o la marca como si fuera reflejo de sus gustos personales, y muchas veces prometen que va a subir la captación de clientes (acquisition) y al final no se materializa en nada que valga la pena.
context: Elena discusses her second growth tactic that never works - rebranding or redesigning marketing sites to drive growth. She describes a common pattern where new CMOs arrive and redesign websites based on personal preferences while promising improved acquisition metrics. Elena emphasizes that these redesigns consistently fail to deliver meaningful performance improvements despite significant investment.
vocabulary_highlights: never materializes into anything meaningful, reflection of their personal taste

speaker: Elena Verna
text: If every single one of your initiatives that you're doing on growth is an experiment that's a problem. It's almost like a disease, like a paralyzing disease.
text_ko: 만약 그로스(growth) 관련해서 하는 모든 이니셔티브(initiatives)가 다 실험(experiment)이라면 그건 문제예요. 거의 조직을 마비시키는 병 같아요.
text_zh: 如果你在增长方面做的每一件事都还在试验阶段，那就有问题了。这简直就像得了病一样，让人动弹不得的那种病。
text_es: Si cada una de las iniciativas de crecimiento que estás haciendo es un experimento, ahí tienes un problema. Es casi como una enfermedad, como una enfermedad que te paraliza.
context: Elena introduces her third point about growth tactics that don't work - over-experimenting on every growth initiative. She argues that when growth teams feel compelled to test everything scientifically before implementation, it becomes counterproductive. This creates a 'paralyzing disease' that slows down progress and prevents teams from taking action based on intuition and experience.
vocabulary_highlights: paralyzing disease

speaker: Elena Verna
text: My north star metric is insights per minute. That's what I try to use whenever I have any live meetings with people so it squarely fits within what I'm optimizing for.
text_ko: 제 가장 중요한 지표인 노스스타 메트릭(north star metric)은 분당 얻는 인사이트(insights per minute)예요. 사람들과 라이브 미팅을 할 때면 항상 그걸 기준으로 삼아요. 그래서 제가 최적화하려는 방향에 딱 맞아떨어져요.
text_zh: 我的北极星指标(north star metric)就是每分钟能获得多少洞察。所以我在跟人开会的时候都会用这个标准，这正好符合我想要优化的目标。
text_es: Mi métrica clave es la cantidad de insights por minuto. Eso es lo que trato de usar siempre que tengo reuniones en vivo con la gente, así que encaja perfectamente con lo que estoy tratando de optimizar.
context: Lenny reads a listener comment praising Elena's ability to pack years of knowledge into every word, noting how her content is worth digesting slowly and repeatedly. Elena responds by revealing her personal performance metric - insights per minute. She explains this is what she optimizes for in all her live meetings and interactions with people.
vocabulary_highlights: north star metric, squarely fits within

speaker: Elena Verna
text: You have a lot of renowned interest in growth hacks, like what is the sure things to get growth. In the age of social media everybody and anybody tries to share their tips and tricks. Oftentimes things that are completely out of context or they are very specific to one example and actually do not apply as a pattern.
text_ko: 많은 사람들이 성장 해킹(growth hacks)에 큰 관심이 있어요. 무엇이 확실히 성장을 가져다주는지 알고 싶어하죠. 소셜미디어 시대엔 누구나 자기만의 팁과 요령을 공유하려 하고, 그런데 그중 상당수가 맥락에 전혀 맞지 않거나 특정 사례에만 해당해서 일반적인 패턴으로 적용되기 어려운 경우가 많아요.
text_zh: 你对增长黑客(growth hacks)特别感兴趣，想知道到底什么招数能确保增长。现在这个社交媒体时代，什么人都在分享自己的小窍门和套路。但很多时候这些东西要么完全不着边际，要么就是针对某个特定案例的，根本没法当作通用模式来用。
text_es: Veo que tienes mucho interés en los growth hacks, como cuáles son las fórmulas seguras para crecer. En la era de las redes sociales, todo el mundo quiere compartir sus trucos y consejos. Muchas veces son cosas completamente fuera de contexto o muy específicas de un caso particular que en realidad no se pueden aplicar como un patrón general.
context: Lenny asks Elena to frame her list of growth tactics that never work. Elena explains that growth is a relatively new field with many newcomers seeking shortcuts and 'sure things' to drive growth. She describes how social media has amplified the problem, with people sharing tips and tricks that are often taken out of context or are too specific to be applied as general patterns across different businesses.
vocabulary_highlights: renowned interest, out of context, apply as a pattern

speaker: Elena Verna
text: The longer you wait, the better it is because that way your entire company will be trained to be responsible for growth as opposed to putting this one island with a growth team and saying, 'They're going to be growing,' and what is the rest of the company doing? Honestly, the longer you wait, the better.
text_ko: 기다릴수록 오히려 좋아요. 그렇게 해야 회사 전체가 성장에 책임을 지는 방식으로 훈련돼요. 반대로 성장팀(growth team) 하나만 따로 떼어놓고 ‘저 팀이 성장시키겠지’ 이렇게 해버리면 나머지 회사는 뭘 하는 건가요? 솔직히, 기다릴수록 더 좋아요.
text_zh: 等得越久其实越好，因为这样你整个公司的人都会被训练成对增长负责，而不是搞个增长团队(growth team)放在那里当孤岛，然后说"增长就是他们的事儿"，那公司其他人在干嘛呢？说真的，晚一点组建专门的增长团队反而更好。
text_es: Mientras más esperes, mejor, porque así toda tu empresa va a estar entrenada para hacerse cargo del crecimiento, en lugar de crear esta islita con un equipo de crecimiento (growth team) y decir "ellos se van a encargar de crecer", ¿y qué hace el resto de la empresa? En serio, mientras más esperes, mejor.
context: Lenny summarizes Elena's advice about waiting longer to hire growth teams, mentioning that many companies wait until they reach millions in ARR. Elena emphasizes that delaying growth team hiring actually benefits companies because it forces the entire organization to take responsibility for growth rather than creating an isolated 'growth island' while the rest of the company remains passive about driving business growth.
