vocabulary_highlights: putting this one island, trained to be responsible for

speaker: Elena Verna
text: I feel like only 30 to 40% of what I've learned in the last 15 to 20 years of being in growth transfers here because we just need to invest in such bigger bets, and innovate, and create new growth loops here, everybody and their mother is starting a vibe coding business nowadays, and we need to figure out how to be ahead of them. And to be ahead of them is not optimization of the problem, it's reinvention of the solution.
text_ko: 지난 15~20년 동안 그로스(growth) 쪽에서 배운 것들 중 여기서 통하는 건 30~40% 정도밖에 안 되는 것 같아요. 이쪽은 훨씬 더 큰 베팅에 투자하고 혁신하고 새로운 성장 루프(growth loops)를 만들어야 해서요. 요즘은 너도 나도 바이브 코딩 비즈니스(vibe coding business)를 시작하고 있어서 우리가 어떻게 그들보다 앞설지 방법을 찾아야 해요. 그리고 앞서간다는 건 문제를 단순히 최적화하는 게 아니라 해결책을 완전히 재창조하는 거예요.
text_zh: 我感觉过去15到20年在增长方面学到的东西，在这里只能用上30%到40%，因为我们得下更大的赌注，要创新，要建立新的增长循环(growth loops)。现在是个人都在搞编程业务，我们必须想办法领先他们。想要领先，光优化问题是不够的，得重新发明解决方案。
text_es: Siento que solo el 30 o 40% de lo que he aprendido en estos últimos 15 o 20 años trabajando en crecimiento me sirve aquí, porque necesitamos apostar mucho más fuerte, innovar, y crear nuevos bucles de crecimiento (growth loops). Hoy en día hasta el perro del vecino está montando un negocio de programación con IA, y tenemos que encontrar la manera de estar por delante de ellos. Y para estar por delante no se trata de optimizar el problema, sino de reinventar completamente la solución.
context: Lenny asks Elena what she's had to unlearn about growth at Lovable. Elena explains that traditional growth tactics don't work in the AI space because the market is moving so quickly. Most of her previous growth knowledge focused on optimizing existing systems, but at Lovable she spends most of her time creating entirely new approaches rather than tweaking what already exists.
vocabulary_highlights: everybody and their mother, vibe coding, reinvention of the solution

speaker: Elena Verna
text: I just feel like I usually spend maybe 5% innovating on growth in my previous roles, right now, I'm spending 95% innovating on growth, and only 5% on optimization.
text_ko: 이전 역할들에선 성장(growth) 혁신에 보통 5% 정도만 썼던 것 같은데, 지금은 성장 혁신에 95%를 쓰고 최적화(optimization)에는 겨우 5%만 쓰고 있어요.
text_zh: 我感觉以前的工作里，我可能只有5%的时间在琢磨增长创新，现在正好反过来了，95%的时间都在研究怎么创新增长，只有5%在做优化。
text_es: Siento que antes en mis roles anteriores dedicaba como un 5% a innovar para el crecimiento, ¿no? Pero ahora estoy invirtiendo el 95% de mi tiempo en innovar para crecer, y solo un 5% en optimización.
context: Elena continues explaining how growth work has fundamentally changed at AI companies like Lovable. In traditional roles, growth teams spend most of their time optimizing existing user journeys and conversion funnels. However, at Lovable, with intense competition and rapidly evolving capabilities, she spends almost all her time creating new growth strategies rather than fine-tuning existing ones.

speaker: Elena Verna
text: One of our biggest strategy is building in public, and it's coupled with employee socials, founder-led socials. And another one is giving your product away a lot, this is part of our growth secret sauce. You have to remove the barrier of entry. If somebody, one of our users stands up and say, hey, I'm going to have a hackathon at my work on Lovable, can you give us some free credits to play with? Why would we prevent a person who wants to do all of the marketing and activating for us from using us?
text_ko: 우리 전략 중 하나는 공개적으로 제품을 만들어가는 '빌딩 인 퍼블릭'(building in public)이고, 직원 소셜(employee socials)이나 창업자 주도 소셜(founder-led socials)과 함께 해요. 또 하나는 제품을 많이 공짜로 풀어주는 건데, 이게 우리의 성장 비법(growth secret sauce)이에요. 진입 장벽(barrier of entry)을 없애야 해요. 만약 어떤 사용자가 "우리 회사에서 Lovable로 해커톤을 하려고 하는데, 써볼 수 있게 무료 크레딧 좀 줄 수 있나요?"라고 하면, 우리를 위해 모든 마케팅과 활성화(activating)를 해주겠다는 사람을 우리가 왜 막겠어요?
text_zh: 我们最重要的策略之一就是公开建设(building in public)，再配合员工社交活动和创始人主导的社交活动。还有一个就是大量免费提供产品，这是我们增长秘诀(growth secret sauce)的一部分。你必须得降低使用门槛。如果我们的用户站出来说，嘿，我要在公司用Lovable办个黑客马拉松(hackathon)，你们能给点免费额度让我们玩玩吗？我们为什么要阻止一个愿意帮我们做营销和用户激活的人使用我们的产品呢？
text_es: Una de nuestras estrategias más grandes es construir en público (building in public), y va de la mano con eventos sociales de empleados y eventos sociales liderados por el fundador. Y otra es regalar mucho tu producto, esto es parte de nuestra salsa secreta de crecimiento. Tienes que quitar las barreras de entrada. Si alguien, uno de nuestros usuarios se para y dice, oye, vamos a hacer un hackathon en mi trabajo con Lovable, ¿nos pueden dar algunos créditos gratis para jugar? ¿Por qué vamos a impedir que una persona que quiere hacer todo el marketing y la activación por nosotros nos use?
context: Lenny asks what growth tactics are actually working for Lovable. Elena describes their core growth strategies: building in public through social media and giving away their product extensively. Rather than viewing free credits as lost revenue, Lovable sees them as marketing costs that enable users to become advocates who do marketing and activation work for the company.
vocabulary_highlights: building in public, secret sauce, barrier of entry, stands up and say

speaker: Elena Verna
text: The only way to create a word of mouth loop is just to blow their socks off.
text_ko: 입소문 루프(word of mouth loop)를 만들려면, 사람들을 말 그대로 깜짝 놀라게 해서 감탄하게 만들어야 해요.
text_zh: 要想形成口碑传播，就得让客户彻底惊艳，超出他们所有预期。
text_es: La única manera de crear un efecto boca a boca es simplemente dejarlos con la boca abierta.
context: Elena is discussing Lovable's growth strategy with Lenny, specifically how they get customers to share their product organically on social media. She explains that the fundamental requirement for word-of-mouth marketing is creating an experience so impressive that users feel compelled to tell others about it.
vocabulary_highlights: blow their socks off, word of mouth loop

speaker: Elena Verna
text: I feel like it's been very clear to me that when you're talking about marketing organic strategy, if you asked me that five years ago, I would've said that's SEO. It's search engine optimization. Go on Google, that's your organic marketing strategy. If you ask me what's your organic marketing strategy right now, to me it's all about social.
text_ko: 유기적 마케팅 전략 얘기를 하면 저한텐 그게 아주 분명했어요. 5년 전만 해도 저한테 물어봤다면 '그건 SEO예요'라고 말했을 거예요. 검색 엔진 최적화(search engine optimization, SEO) — 구글(Google)에 노출되는 게 유기적 마케팅 전략이라고 생각했거든요. 근데 지금 제게 유기적 마케팅 전략이 뭐냐고 물어보면, 저는 이제 전부 소셜(social)이라고 봐요.
text_zh: 我觉得这个问题对我来说挺明确的，说到有机营销策略(organic marketing strategy)，你要是五年前问我，我肯定会说那就是SEO，就是搜索引擎优化(search engine optimization)，在谷歌上做文章，这就是你的有机营销策略。但你现在问我什么是有机营销策略，我觉得现在全都是围绕社交媒体来做的。
text_es: Me parece súper claro que cuando hablas de estrategia de marketing orgánico, si me hubieras preguntado eso hace cinco años, te habría dicho que era SEO. Optimización para motores de búsqueda. Métete en Google, esa era tu estrategia de marketing orgánico. Si ahora me preguntas cuál es tu estrategia de marketing orgánico, para mí todo gira en torno a las redes sociales.
context: Elena discusses how marketing channels have fundamentally changed for AI companies. She explains that traditional organic marketing relied heavily on search engine optimization and Google traffic. However, for modern AI companies, organic marketing now centers around social media presence, including what CEOs and employees post, influencer marketing, and user-generated content across social platforms.

speaker: Elena Verna
text: I actually think that's quite false, because new grads, especially AI-native new grads... We have multiple new graduates at Lovable that are working, and I learned so much from them. And you need to obviously have the right atmosphere where people with experience, like a old guard like me, that can look at the new guard and really hear them and see them.
text_ko: 저는 그게 사실 꽤 잘못된 생각이라고 생각해요. 신입들, 특히 AI 네이티브(AI-native) 신입들한테서요... 저희 Lovable에 일하는 신입이 여러 명 있는데, 그들한테서 정말 많은 걸 배웠어요. 그리고 당연히 경험 많은 사람들, 즉 저 같은 올드 가드(old guard)가 뉴 가드(new guard)를 진심으로 듣고 보고 인정해줄 수 있는 분위기가 필요해요.
text_zh: 我觉得这个说法其实挺不对的，因为应届生，特别是那些AI原生代(AI-native)的应届生...我们Lovable就有好几个应届毕业生在工作，我从他们身上学到了很多东西。当然你得营造一个合适的氛围，让我这种有经验的老家伙能够真正去倾听和观察这些新人。
text_es: En realidad creo que eso es bastante falso, porque los recién graduados, especialmente los que son nativos de la IA... Tenemos varios recién graduados en Lovable que están trabajando, y he aprendido muchísimo de ellos. Y obviamente necesitas tener el ambiente adecuado donde la gente con experiencia, como un veterano como yo, pueda realmente escuchar a la nueva generación y verlos de verdad.
context: Elena addresses concerns about AI eliminating entry-level jobs, particularly for new graduates. She argues this narrative is incorrect and explains that AI-native new graduates actually bring valuable skills to companies. She describes how at Lovable, experienced workers like herself learn from new graduates who understand AI capabilities without the baggage of traditional approaches.
vocabulary_highlights: AI-native, old guard, new guard

speaker: Elena Verna
text: It shouldn't be minimal viable product anymore. Viability is left back in 2010s. Now it's minimal lovable product. That's the only thing that matters.
text_ko: 이제는 더 이상 최소 실행 가능 제품(minimum viable product, MVP)으로는 안 돼요. '생존 가능성(viability)'에 머물러 있던 건 2010년대에 이미 지나갔어요. 지금은 최소 사랑받는 제품(minimum lovable product)만이 유일하게 중요한 기준이에요.
text_zh: 现在不应该再说最小可行产品(minimal viable product)了。可行性这个概念已经是2010年代的老黄历了。现在讲的是最小可爱产品(minimal lovable product)，这才是唯一重要的。
text_es: Ya no debería ser producto mínimo viable. La viabilidad se quedó en los 2010. Ahora es producto mínimo adorable (minimal lovable product). Eso es lo único que importa.
context: Lenny summarizes that one key growth lever for AI companies is building something that genuinely impresses users in a growing market. Elena responds by reframing the classic startup concept of MVP (Minimum Viable Product). She argues that in today's competitive AI landscape, simply being viable isn't enough - products must be genuinely lovable and delightful to stand out.
vocabulary_highlights: minimal lovable product

speaker: Eli Schwartz
text: I think of SEO as a product. The product managers are the people that should be thinking about this SEO question because it's a product question. Product people need to think about how do we position this to the user that is not going to find out about this from a social channel, that's not going to be attracted by an ad? This is a user that's doing their own self-discovery journey.
text_ko: 저는 검색엔진최적화(SEO)를 하나의 제품(product)으로 봐요. 그래서 이건 제품 관련 문제라 프로덕트 매니저들(product managers)이 고민해야 해요. 프로덕트 담당자들은 소셜 채널(social channel)에서 알게 되지 않고 광고(ad)에 끌리지도 않을 그런 사용자에게 이걸 어떻게 포지셔닝할지 생각해야 해요. 이런 사용자는 스스로 탐색하는 여정(self-discovery journey)을 하고 있어요.
text_zh: 我觉得SEO就是一个产品。产品经理们应该去考虑SEO这个问题，因为这本质上就是个产品问题。产品的人需要想想，我们怎么把这个东西推给那些不会从社交渠道了解到我们，也不会被广告吸引的用户？这些用户是在自己主动去找、去发现的。
text_es: Yo veo el SEO como un producto. Los product managers son los que deberían estar pensando en el tema del SEO porque es una cuestión de producto. La gente de producto tiene que pensar en cómo le presentamos esto al usuario que no se va a enterar por redes sociales, que no lo va a atraer un anuncio. Este es un usuario que está en su propio proceso de descubrimiento.
context: Lenny asks Eli what people should do to be successful in the new paradigm where AI answers are changing how SEO works. Eli explains that SEO should be approached as a product challenge rather than just a marketing challenge. He argues that product managers should be the ones thinking about SEO because they need to understand what users are searching for and how to position the product for users who discover it through organic search rather than ads or social media.
vocabulary_highlights: self-discovery journey, position this to the user, attracted by an ad
topics: Product Management, Growth & Marketing, Strategy & Planning

speaker: Eli Schwartz
text: Transparently, I thought this was going to be an apocalypse. So I shared about a year ago that it's going to be an apocalypse. We have not seen it yet, and a lot of people are declaring victory that there's no apocalypse because we have not seen it yet. However, this thing just launched in a way that I think it will start impacting traffic.
text_ko: 솔직히 저는 이게 아포칼립스가 될 거라고 봤어요. 그래서 약 1년 전에 그렇게 얘기했어요. 아직 그 정도는 안 왔고, 안 왔다고 해서 ‘아포칼립스 아니다’라며 승리 선언하는 사람들도 많아요. 그런데 이번에 이렇게 출시된 걸 보니 트래픽(traffic)에 영향을 주기 시작할 것 같아요.
text_zh: 说实话，我当时觉得这玩意儿会是场灾难。所以大概一年前我就说过，这会是场灾难。但到现在我们还没看到，很多人就开始庆祝胜利了，说什么没有灾难发生。不过，这东西刚刚以一种新的方式推出，我觉得它开始会对流量产生冲击了。
text_es: Para ser totalmente honesto, yo pensaba que esto iba a ser un apocalipsis. Así que hace como un año anduve diciendo que se venía el apocalipsis. Todavía no lo hemos visto, y mucha gente ya está cantando victoria diciendo que no hay apocalipsis porque aún no ha pasado nada. Pero esta cosa acaba de lanzarse de una manera que creo que ya va a empezar a afectar el tráfico.
context: Lenny asks what impact Eli has seen on SEO and search results as AI Overviews have rolled out. Eli admits he initially predicted a catastrophic impact on SEO traffic from AI answers in search results, but explains that the full impact hasn't been seen yet because Google only recently launched AI Overviews more broadly. He notes that Google had previously rolled back the feature after some embarrassing results when it first launched.
vocabulary_highlights: transparently, declaring victory, impacting traffic

speaker: Eli Schwartz
text: Up until AI Overviews, whoever won on that long form piece of content would get that first click. But now that doesn't exist anymore. You just go to Google and Google tells you, 'These are the tools. Oh, you're looking for a new CRM? This is what a CRM is. You want to know, do you need a CRM or do you just need a calendar?' Look at that and Google will just tell you in a paragraph, and now you've redirected your search somewhere else into middle of the funnel.
text_ko: AI 오버뷰(AI Overviews) 나오기 전까진 롱폼 콘텐츠(long-form content)에서 이긴 사람이 첫 클릭을 가져갔어요. 그런데 이제 그게 사라졌어요. 그냥 구글에 가면 구글이 “사용할 수 있는 도구들이 이거예요. 새 고객관계관리시스템(CRM)을 찾고 계신가요? CRM이 뭔지, CRM이 필요한지 아니면 단순히 캘린더만 있으면 되는지” 한 단락으로 알려줘요. 그걸 보고 나면 검색이 바로 퍼널 중간(middle of the funnel)으로 옮겨져 버려요.
text_zh: 在AI Overviews(AI概览)出来之前，谁的长内容做得好，谁就能拿到第一个点击。但现在这套玩法不管用了。你去Google搜索，Google直接告诉你："这些是工具。哦，你在找新的CRM？CRM就是这个意思。你想知道自己到底需要CRM还是只要个日历就够了？"看到了吧，Google直接用一段话就把答案给你了，然后你的搜索就被引到别的地方去了，直接进入漏斗中段。
text_es: Hasta que llegaron los AI Overviews, quien se llevara el primer lugar con ese contenido largo se quedaba con el primer clic. Pero ahora eso ya no existe. Simplemente vas a Google y Google te dice: "Estas son las herramientas. ¿Ah, buscas un CRM nuevo? Esto es lo que es un CRM. ¿Quieres saber si necesitas un CRM o te basta con un calendario?" Le echas un vistazo y Google te lo explica todo en un párrafo, y ahora ya redirigiste tu búsqueda a otra parte, directo al medio del embudo (middle of the funnel).
context: Lenny asks Eli to help explain the distinction between top-of-funnel and mid-funnel searches in the context of AI's impact on SEO. Eli is explaining how AI Overviews are changing the search landscape by providing direct answers to broad, top-of-funnel queries. He uses the example of someone searching for podcast tools or CRM software, showing how Google now answers these general questions directly rather than sending users to ranking websites.
vocabulary_highlights: long form piece of content, redirected your search, middle of the funnel

speaker: Eli Schwartz
text: The biggest myth in SEO is that you could just build links, and link building is the secret source and the secret sauce to growing your SEO footprint. That's totally wrong, because the way most people build links is they buy these guest posts, or they pay for links on low authority websites that sort of look like they might have authority, and it doesn't really benefit anyone because no one's reading these sites.
text_ko: 검색엔진 최적화(SEO)에서 가장 큰 미신은 '그냥 링크만 만들면 된다'는 거예요. 링크 빌딩(link building)이 SEO 입지(footprint)를 키우는 비밀의 비법이라는 건데, 그건 완전히 틀렸어요. 대부분 사람들이 링크를 만드는 방식은 게스트 포스트(guest posts)를 사거나 겉보기엔 권위 있어 보이지만 사실 권위가 낮은 사이트들(low authority websites)에 돈을 주고 링크를 다는 건데, 그런 사이트들은 아무도 읽지 않아서 사실 누구에게도 도움이 안 돼요.
text_zh: SEO最大的误区就是以为光靠建链接就行，好像链接建设(link building)就是提升SEO效果的万能秘籍。这想法完全错了，因为大部分人建链接的方法就是花钱买客座文章(guest posts)，或者在一些看起来有点权威但其实很水的网站上付费发链接，这根本没什么用，因为压根没人看这些网站。
text_es: El mito más grande en SEO es pensar que solo necesitas construir enlaces, que el link building es la fórmula secreta para hacer crecer tu posicionamiento. Eso está completamente equivocado, porque la mayoría de la gente construye enlaces comprando guest posts o pagando por enlaces en sitios web de baja autoridad que aparentan tener credibilidad, y al final no le sirve a nadie porque nadie está leyendo esos sitios.
context: Lenny asks Eli about the relationship between brand building and SEO, especially in the world of AI. Eli explains one of the biggest misconceptions in SEO - that link building is the key to success. He argues that most link building strategies involve paying for guest posts or links on low-quality websites that don't actually help because they don't drive real traffic or engagement. Instead, he advocates for building genuine brand recognition and mentions.
vocabulary_highlights: secret source and the secret sauce, SEO footprint, low authority websites

speaker: Eli Schwartz
text: I think step one is the step that almost everyone misses on SEO, which is be the user. Try to understand who your user is. There've been so many companies, and SurveyMonkey was a great example. One, I spent seven years at SurveyMonkey, and when everyone got onboarded at SurveyMonkey, they gave you a SurveyMonkey account and told you that you should run a survey.
text_ko: 제 생각에 첫 번째 단계는 대부분 사람들이 검색엔진최적화(SEO)에서 놓치는 부분인데, 바로 사용자 입장이 돼 보는 거예요. 누가 우리의 사용자인지 이해하려고 노력해 보세요. 정말 많은 회사들이 그랬고, SurveyMonkey가 좋은 예였어요. 제가 SurveyMonkey에서 7년 있었는데, 새로 들어오는 사람들은 온보딩(onboarded) 때 SurveyMonkey 계정을 하나 주고 설문 하나 해보라고 했어요.
text_zh: 我觉得做SEO(搜索引擎优化)第一步，也是几乎所有人都会忽略的一步，就是要站在用户的角度去思考。你得真正了解你的用户是谁。有太多公司都犯这个毛病，SurveyMonkey就是个很好的例子。我在SurveyMonkey待了七年，那时候每个新人入职，公司都会给你开个SurveyMonkey账户，然后告诉你应该去做个调查问卷。
text_es: Creo que el primer paso es el que casi todo mundo se salta en SEO, y es ponerte en los zapatos del usuario. Trata de entender quién es tu usuario. He visto muchísimas empresas, y SurveyMonkey fue un ejemplo perfecto. Mira, estuve siete años en SurveyMonkey, y cuando llegaba gente nueva a la empresa, les daban una cuenta de SurveyMonkey y les decían que tenían que hacer una encuesta.
context: Lenny asks Eli for step-by-step advice for someone just starting with SEO in this new world of AI and LLMs. Eli emphasizes that the first and most crucial step that companies often skip is developing user empathy. He uses his experience at SurveyMonkey as an example, explaining how employees were given accounts but rarely used the product themselves, leading to a lack of understanding of customer motivations and search behavior.
vocabulary_highlights: be the user, customer empathy, onboarded

speaker: Eli Schwartz
text: If you can't answer the question about what is it that someone's going to do a search on, then don't do SEO because SEO is about appealing to that user. If you can understand what the user should do around looking for whatever product you have, then that's the first step for SEO.
text_ko: 사람들이 무엇을 검색할지 답할 수 없다면 검색엔진최적화(SEO)를 하지 마세요. SEO는 결국 그 사용자에게 어필하는 작업이에요. 반대로 사용자가 당신의 제품을 찾으려고 할 때 어떤 행동을 해야 하는지 이해할 수 있다면, 그게 SEO의 첫걸음이에요.
text_zh: 如果你连用户会搜什么都不知道，那就别做SEO(搜索引擎优化)了，因为SEO就是要抓住用户的心。你得先搞清楚用户会怎么搜你的产品，这才是做SEO的第一步。
text_es: Si no puedes responder qué es lo que alguien va a buscar en Google, entonces mejor no te metas con SEO porque el SEO se trata de conectar con ese usuario. Si logras entender qué debería hacer el usuario cuando busca tu producto o lo que sea que tengas, ahí tienes el primer paso para el SEO.
context: Continuing his explanation of the first step in SEO strategy, Eli provides a simple but powerful test for whether a company should invest in SEO at all. He argues that if you cannot clearly articulate what users would search for to find your product or solve their problem, then SEO is not the right channel to invest in. This connects to his broader theme that SEO should be user-focused rather than just technically focused.
vocabulary_highlights: appealing to that user, first step for SEO

speaker: Elizabeth Stone
text: It's very reflective of Reed Hastings as founder of Netflix. So when he founded Netflix and grew the company over time, it was with a belief that there could be a different approach to building a company that would make it a place that people thrived in and loved being and would feel different than other places, both in the quality of that talent density, but even more importantly, the excellence and the outcomes. And that that's where people would derive a lot of sense of fulfillment.
text_ko: 이건 넷플릭스 창업자 리드 헤이스팅스의 성향을 잘 보여줘요. 그는 회사를 세우고 키워오면서 사람들이 잘 성장하고 일하는 걸 즐기며 다른 곳과는 확실히 다르게 느낄 수 있는 회사를 만들 수 있다는 믿음으로 움직였어요. 그 차이는 단지 인재 밀도(talent density)의 수준뿐만 아니라, 더 중요한 건 탁월함과 성과(outcomes)에 있어요. 그래서 사람들이 그런 곳에서 많은 성취감과 만족을 얻을 거라고 본 거예요.
text_zh: 这很能体现Netflix创始人里德·黑斯廷斯的想法。他创办Netflix并一步步把公司做大的时候，就有个信念——可以用一种不一样的方式来建公司，让员工在这里真正能发光发热，真心喜欢待在这里，感觉跟其他公司就是不一样。不光是人才密度(talent density)高，更重要的是追求卓越和成果。他觉得员工就是要从这里面获得成就感。
text_es: Esto refleja mucho la mentalidad de Reed Hastings como fundador de Netflix. Cuando él creó Netflix y fue haciendo crecer la empresa con el tiempo, lo hizo con la convicción de que podía haber una forma distinta de construir una compañía que la convirtiera en un lugar donde la gente realmente prosperara y le encantara trabajar, que se sintiera diferente a otros lugares, tanto por la calidad de esa densidad de talento, pero aún más importante, por la excelencia y los resultados. Y que ahí es donde la gente encontraría una gran sensación de realización personal.
context: Lenny asks Elizabeth about Netflix's culture of high talent density and why it's so important to the company. Elizabeth explains that Netflix's unique culture stems from founder Reed Hastings' vision to create a different type of company where people would thrive through excellence and high-quality outcomes. She emphasizes that this cultural foundation has been deeply embedded in Netflix since its early days and requires maintaining very high standards for talent.
vocabulary_highlights: deeply seated, derive a lot of sense of fulfillment, thrived in

speaker: Elizabeth Stone
text: We can't really have any of the other aspects of the culture, including candor, learning, seeking excellence in improvement, freedom and responsibility if you don't start with high talent density. And in order to do that, you have to really hold yourself to a lot of stuff that doesn't feel like natural human behavior.
text_ko: 높은 인재 밀도(high talent density)부터 시작하지 않으면 솔직함(candor), 학습(learning), 개선에서의 탁월함 추구(seeking excellence in improvement), 그리고 자유와 책임(freedom and responsibility) 같은 문화의 다른 요소들은 사실상 가질 수 없어요. 그걸 위해서는 본능적으로 자연스럽게 느껴지지 않는 많은 것들을 스스로에게 엄격히 요구해야 해요.
text_zh: 如果没有高人才密度(high talent density)这个基础，其他的企业文化都是空谈，什么坦诚沟通、持续学习、追求卓越、自由与责任，统统都搞不起来。要做到这一点，你就得逼着自己做很多违背人性的事情。
text_es: No podemos tener realmente ninguno de los otros aspectos de la cultura empresarial, incluyendo la transparencia, el aprendizaje, la búsqueda de la excelencia en la mejora, la libertad y la responsabilidad, si no empiezas con una alta densidad de talento. Y para lograr eso, tienes que exigirte muchas cosas que no se sienten como comportamiento humano natural.
context: Lenny is asking Elizabeth to explain Netflix's focus on high talent density and why it's so critical. Elizabeth explains that high talent density is the foundation that enables all other aspects of Netflix's culture to function effectively. She notes that maintaining this standard requires behaviors that go against natural human tendencies, such as giving difficult feedback and making tough decisions about people who aren't meeting the bar.
vocabulary_highlights: hold yourself to, doesn't feel like natural human behavior

speaker: Elizabeth Stone
text: The reason the keeper test and that question is useful is because no one wants to think that way. It's very hard to say to someone, 'I think this isn't the right fit. I think you should move on from the company.' So we have to introduce some of those reflections in order to encourage the behavior.
text_ko: 키퍼 테스트(keeper test)와 그 질문이 유용한 이유는 아무도 그런 식으로 생각하고 싶어 하지 않기 때문이에요. 누군가에게 '이 사람은 잘 맞지 않는 것 같아요. 회사에서 떠나는 게 좋겠어요.'라고 말하기는 정말 어려워요. 그래서 우리는 일부러 그런 생각을 하게 해서 그런 행동을 유도해야 해요.
text_zh: 这个留用测试(keeper test)和那个问题之所以有用，是因为没人愿意往那个方向想。你很难跟一个人说，"我觉得你不太适合这个岗位，你应该考虑离开公司了。" 所以我们必须引入一些这样的思考，来推动大家做出这种行为。
text_es: La razón por la que la prueba del guardameta (keeper test) y esa pregunta son útiles es porque nadie quiere pensar de esa manera. Es muy difícil decirle a alguien: "Creo que esto no está funcionando para ti. Creo que deberías buscar otras oportunidades fuera de la empresa." Entonces tenemos que introducir este tipo de reflexiones para fomentar ese comportamiento.
context: Lenny asks Elizabeth about Netflix's 'keeper test' - a mental framework where managers ask themselves if they would fight to keep someone if that person said they were leaving. Elizabeth explains that this tool helps managers make difficult decisions about team members who may not be meeting Netflix's high standards. The keeper test forces uncomfortable but necessary conversations about fit and performance that managers naturally want to avoid.
vocabulary_highlights: keeper test, isn't the right fit, move on from the company

speaker: Elizabeth Stone
text: I have felt a lot more at ease by having these conversations than by not having them. So in many roles I've had, I haven't been sure how I was doing or things I could be doing better on, and I didn't quite know how to get that information. And that made me feel much more stressed or nervous or at risk than having it be part of the culture to have those conversations.
text_ko: 이런 대화를 나누면 안 나눌 때보다 훨씬 마음이 편해요. 맡았던 많은 역할에서는 제가 잘하고 있는지, 뭘 더 잘할 수 있는지 확신이 없었고 그런 정보를 어떻게 얻어야 할지도 몰랐어요. 그래서 그런 대화가 문화의 일부로 자리잡지 않으면 훨씬 더 스트레스와 불안, 위험을 느꼈어요.
text_zh: 有了这些对话交流之后，我感觉轻松多了，比不谈要好得多。我之前在很多岗位上都搞不清楚自己做得怎么样，也不知道哪些地方可以改进，又不太好意思主动去问。这样反而让我压力更大，心里也没底，总担心出问题。现在公司文化就是鼓励大家多沟通，反而踏实多了。
text_es: Me he sentido mucho más tranquilo teniendo estas conversaciones que evitándolas. En muchos puestos que he tenido, no tenía claro cómo lo estaba haciendo o en qué cosas podría mejorar, y no sabía muy bien cómo conseguir esa información. Y eso me generaba mucho más estrés y nervios, me hacía sentir más vulnerable que cuando es parte de la cultura del lugar tener este tipo de conversaciones.
context: Lenny expresses concern that Netflix's keeper test culture might create constant anxiety among employees who worry about being fired. Elizabeth responds by sharing her personal experience, explaining that regular candid conversations about performance actually reduce stress rather than increase it. She argues that knowing where you stand through ongoing feedback is less stressful than being uncertain about your performance in environments without regular feedback.
vocabulary_highlights: at ease, at risk

speaker: Elizabeth Stone
text: At Netflix we try really hard to say we're looking for the new perspective or the person who's actually going to make us stronger as a team. So thinking about additive skills, additive perspectives, people who are going to push our thinking on something. That tends to help us with thinking about talent density because you're constantly introducing people to the team who uplevel.
text_ko: 넷플릭스에서는 새로운 관점이나 팀을 실제로 더 강하게 만들어줄 사람을 찾고 있다고 계속 말하려고 정말 노력해요. 그래서 보탬이 되는 역량(additive skills)이나 보태는 관점(additive perspectives), 우리 생각을 밀어붙여 한 단계 더 끌어올려줄 사람들을 생각해요. 그런 접근 방식이 인재 밀도(talent density)를 고민할 때 도움이 돼요. 팀에 계속해서 수준을 끌어올리는(uplevel) 사람들을 들여오게 되니까요.
text_zh: 在Netflix我们特别注重找那些能带来新视角的人，就是那种真正能让我们团队变得更强的人。我们会考虑那些技能互补、视角独特的人才，那些能推动我们思维的人。这样做其实有助于我们提升人才密度(talent density)，因为你在不断地往团队里引入那些能提升整体水平(uplevel)的人。
text_es: En Netflix nos esforzamos mucho por decir que buscamos esa perspectiva nueva o la persona que realmente va a fortalecer al equipo. Entonces pensamos en habilidades que sumen, perspectivas que aporten, gente que nos va a desafiar a pensar diferente sobre algo. Eso nos ayuda con el tema de densidad de talento (talent density) porque constantemente estás metiendo gente al equipo que eleva el nivel.
context: Lenny asks Elizabeth for advice on how other companies can maintain high talent density in their hiring. Elizabeth explains Netflix's approach to hiring, which goes beyond just finding qualified candidates. Instead of simply checking off required skills, Netflix looks for people who will raise the bar for the entire team by bringing new perspectives and challenging existing thinking. This approach ensures that each new hire strengthens the overall talent level of the organization.
vocabulary_highlights: additive skills, additive perspectives, push our thinking, uplevel

speaker: Elizabeth Stone
text: If we want to create a work environment where we are not prescriptive about how people solve problems or the scope of problems that they could tackle, assuming they're highly impactful for the business, and we don't have a lot of process around that work, we get a lot of those things because we give people the freedom and the space to explore and question things and experiment in a way with solutions.
text_ko: 사람들이 문제를 어떻게 풀어야 하는지나 다룰 문제의 범위(scope)를 규정하지 않고(prescriptive), 그 일이 비즈니스에 큰 영향이 있다면 그 일에 대해 프로세스(process)를 많이 두지 않는 근무 환경을 만들고 싶다면, 사람들에게 탐색하고 질문하고 해결책을 실험할 수 있는 자유와 여지를 줘야 해요. 그래서 그런 것들이 많이 나와요.
text_zh: 如果我们想打造一个工作环境，不去规定员工具体怎么解决问题，也不限制他们能处理什么样的问题——只要对公司业务有重大影响就行，而且我们也不搞那么多条条框框的流程，这样我们就能收获很多成果，因为我们给了员工自由度和空间，让他们去探索、去质疑、去试验各种解决方案。
text_es: Si queremos crear un ambiente de trabajo donde no les digamos a las personas exactamente cómo resolver los problemas o qué tan grandes pueden ser los problemas que aborden - siempre y cuando generen un impacto importante para el negocio - y no tengamos muchos procesos rígidos alrededor de ese trabajo, conseguimos muchas de esas cosas porque les damos a las personas la libertad y el espacio para explorar, cuestionar cosas y experimentar con las soluciones.
context: Lenny asks what practices Netflix does that other companies shouldn't attempt because their talent level is so high. Elizabeth explains Netflix's approach to 'freedom and responsibility' - giving employees significant autonomy to solve problems without prescriptive processes or strict guardrails. She emphasizes that this level of freedom only works when you have extremely talented people with strong judgment, as it would be dangerous with lower talent density.
vocabulary_highlights: prescriptive about, scope of problems, highly impactful

speaker: Elizabeth Stone
text: It truly is not about time. I even found myself in a meeting earlier today saying, 'If we're clear on the objectives of something, it might be that the last 20% of polish on the document is a really bad use of time.' The reason we're doing the quarterly business review is to have a really candid conversation about how we think things are going, to have a debate about things where maybe we're stuck.
text_ko: 정말 시간 문제가 아니에요. 저도 오늘 회의에서 “어떤 일의 목적이 분명하면 문서의 마지막 20%를 다듬는 데 시간을 쓰는 건 오히려 안 좋은 시간 투자일 수 있다”라고 말했어요. 우리가 분기별 비즈니스 리뷰(quarterly business review)를 하는 이유는 지금 상황을 어떻게 보고 있는지 솔직하게 얘기하고, 혹시 막혀 있는 부분들에 대해 토론하려는 거예요.
text_zh: 说真的，这跟时间没关系。我今天开会的时候还在说，"如果我们对目标很清楚，那花时间去打磨文档的最后20%可能就是在浪费时间。" 我们做季度业务回顾(quarterly business review)的目的，就是要开诚布公地聊聊我们觉得事情进展怎么样，对那些可能卡住的问题好好讨论讨论。
text_es: Realmente no es cuestión de tiempo. Incluso hoy más temprano en una junta me escuché diciendo: "Si tenemos claros los objetivos de algo, puede ser que ese último 20% de pulir el documento sea una pérdida de tiempo terrible." La razón por la que hacemos la revisión trimestral del negocio es para tener una conversación muy honesta sobre cómo creemos que van las cosas, para debatir sobre esas cosas donde quizás estamos atorados.
context: Lenny asks Elizabeth how to maintain high standards without burning out or working excessive hours. Elizabeth clarifies that excellence isn't about time spent but about focusing on the right outcomes. She gives an example of advising her team not to over-polish documents for quarterly business reviews, explaining that the goal is meaningful discussion and debate, not perfect presentation materials. This shows how to maintain high standards while being strategic about where to invest effort.
vocabulary_highlights: 20% of polish, really bad use of time, candid conversation

speaker: Emilie Gerber
text: No one ever gets this tactical in PR. There's just so much theoretical conversation and examining the big blunders, but at the end of the day, if you're a startup that wants to get coverage for your company, you need to know actually the steps to take to do it.
text_ko: 홍보(PR) 쪽에선 이렇게 실무적인 전술까지 들어가는 경우가 거의 없어요. 대부분 이론적인 얘기나 큰 실수 사례만 분석하죠. 그런데 결국, 회사 언론 보도(coverage)를 받으려는 스타트업(startup)이라면 실제로 어떤 단계들을 밟아야 하는지 정확히 알아야 해요.
text_zh: 做PR的时候，很少有人会讲得这么具体。大家总是在那儿聊理论，分析那些大翻车案例，但说到底，如果你是个创业公司，想让媒体报道你们，你得知道具体怎么操作才行。
text_es: Nadie se pone tan específico con las relaciones públicas. Siempre hay mucha conversación teórica y análisis de las grandes metidas de pata, but at the end of the day, si eres una startup que quiere cobertura mediática para tu empresa, necesitas saber cuáles son los pasos concretos que tienes que dar para lograrlo.
context: Lenny asks Emilie about different publications and what each one is best suited for story-wise. Emilie is explaining why she loves getting into tactical PR advice, contrasting it with the typical high-level PR discussions. She emphasizes that while theoretical conversations about PR disasters are common, startups need concrete, actionable steps to actually secure media coverage for their companies.
vocabulary_highlights: get this tactical, big blunders, at the end of the day

speaker: Emilie Gerber
text: You can get so in the weeds with your own messaging that you want to set up this massive problem statement, you want to make it a huge trend story, but if you're very straightforward and you're pattern matching, it's generally actually going to work.
text_ko: 자기 메시징(messaging)에 너무 파고들다 보면 거창한 문제 정의(problem statement)를 세우고 이걸 큰 트렌드 이야기로 만들고 싶어질 수 있어요. 그런데 훨씬 직접적이고 단순하게 접근해서 패턴 매칭(pattern matching)을 하면, 보통은 실제로 더 잘 통해요.
text_zh: 你很容易陷入到自己的信息传达里钻牛角尖，总想搞个特别宏大的问题陈述，想把它包装成一个巨大的趋势故事，但其实你要是直截了当一点，找准规律去套用，通常效果反而会更好。
text_es: Puedes meterte tanto en los detalles de tu propio mensaje que quieres plantear este problema gigantesco, quieres convertirlo en una gran historia de tendencias, pero si vas directo al grano y buscas patrones que ya funcionan, generalmente te va a dar resultado.
context: Lenny asks about pitching funding stories to reporters. Emilie is explaining common mistakes founders make when pitching their funding announcements. She describes how founders often overcomplicate their messaging by trying to create elaborate market narratives, when a simple, direct approach that follows established patterns is much more effective for getting media coverage.
vocabulary_highlights: get so in the weeds, pattern matching

speaker: Emilie Gerber
text: I'm of the belief that it does not matter as much as many people think it does. And I explained this on calls where they ask, 'Oh, tell me about your Rolodex, or who is your relationships with?' First of all, media's changing so fast.
text_ko: 저는 그게 많은 사람들이 생각하는 것만큼 그렇게 중요하지 않다고 생각해요. 통화할 때 사람들이 '롤로덱스(Rolodex)에 대해 말해 주세요, 혹은 누구랑 인맥이 있으세요?'라고 물으면 제가 그렇게 설명했어요. 우선 미디어(media)가 너무 빨리 변하고 있어요.
text_zh: 我觉得这个没有很多人想的那么重要。在电话里有人问我"跟我说说你的人脉圈，你都认识哪些人？"的时候，我都会解释这个问题。首先，媒体行业变化太快了。
text_es: Yo creo que no es tan importante como mucha gente piensa. Y lo he explicado en llamadas donde me preguntan, 'Oye, cuéntame de tu Rolodex, o ¿con quién tienes relaciones?' Para empezar, los medios están cambiando súper rápido.
context: Lenny asks about the importance of having warm connections to reporters versus cold outreach. Emilie is challenging the common assumption that success in PR depends heavily on having existing relationships with journalists. She argues that the media landscape changes too rapidly for relationship-based strategies to be sustainable, and that well-executed cold outreach can be just as effective as warm introductions.
vocabulary_highlights: Rolodex

speaker: Emilie Gerber
text: A lot of companies want to position themselves as category creators, and I actually hate that. It doesn't work. It doesn't land with press, and most of the time it's not totally true.
text_ko: 많은 회사들이 '카테고리 크리에이터(category creator)'로 자리매김하려고 하는데, 솔직히 저는 그게 별로예요. 잘 통하지 않아요. 언론에도 잘 안 먹히고, 대부분은 완전 사실도 아닌 경우가 많아요.
text_zh: 很多公司都想把自己包装成品类开创者(category creators)，说实话我特别讨厌这套。这招根本不管用，媒体也不买账，而且大多数时候压根就不是事实。
text_es: Muchas empresas quieren posicionarse como creadoras de categoría, y la verdad es que eso me parece fatal. No funciona para nada. No les compra la prensa, y la mayoría de las veces ni siquiera es del todo cierto.
context: Lenny asks about additional pitch advice for getting reporter attention. Emilie is sharing her controversial opinion about category creation as a PR strategy. She explains that while companies love to position themselves as creating entirely new market categories, this approach rarely resonates with journalists who prefer clear comparisons to existing solutions they already understand.
vocabulary_highlights: land with press

speaker: Emilie Gerber
text: And so instead, it's actually really great when you can talk about how you are doing what X household name does, but better for X reasons, and that works so well. I'll put that in subject lines. I'll put company taking on whatever Salesforce with X approach.
text_ko: 그래서 오히려, ‘우리가 그 유명 브랜드(household name)가 하는 일을 똑같이 하지만 X 이유 때문에 더 잘한다’고 말할 수 있으면 진짜 좋아요. 그게 정말 잘 먹혀요. 저는 그걸 이메일 제목(subject lines)에 넣을 거예요. 예를 들어 ‘우리 회사가 X 접근법(approach)으로 Salesforce에 도전한다’ 같은 식으로요.
text_zh: 所以换个思路，其实这样说特别好使：我们做的事儿跟某某大牌公司一样，但是我们在这几个方面做得更好，这招真的很管用。我会直接把这个写在邮件标题里，比如说"某某公司用X方法挑战Salesforce"这样的。
text_es: Y entonces, la verdad es que funciona genial cuando puedes hablar de cómo estás haciendo lo mismo que hace X empresa conocida, pero mejor por X razones, y eso funciona súper bien. Lo pongo en los asuntos de los emails. Pongo "empresa compitiendo contra Salesforce con X enfoque".
context: Following her criticism of category creation, Emilie explains her preferred alternative approach for positioning companies in PR pitches. Instead of claiming to create new categories, she recommends positioning startups as better alternatives to well-known incumbents. This gives reporters an immediate frame of reference and makes the story easier to understand and write about.
vocabulary_highlights: household name, taking on

speaker: Emilie Gerber
text: I think doing social well is very hard. So you gave Aaron from Vox as an example, that was all 100% him. I think I helped with one tweet once about a Microsoft partnership that we did, and I was so excited.
text_ko: 소셜 미디어(social media)를 잘하는 건 정말 어렵다고 생각해요. 예로 드신 Vox의 Aaron은 그거 완전히 100% 혼자 하신 거였어요. 저는 우리가 했던 마이크로소프트(Microsoft)와의 파트너십 관련 트윗을 한 번 도운 적이 있는데, 그때 정말 신났어요.
text_zh: 我觉得做好社交媒体真的很难。你刚才提到Vox的Aaron那个例子，那完全就是他一个人搞定的。我记得有一次我们跟微软合作，我帮忙发了一条推，当时兴奋得不行。
text_es: Creo que hacer bien las redes sociales es súper difícil. Entonces mencionaste a Aaron de Vox como ejemplo, eso era 100% él. Creo que yo ayudé con un tweet una vez sobre una alianza con Microsoft que hicimos, y estaba súper emocionado.
context: Lenny asks about the difference between going after traditional media versus building your own social media following. Emilie is explaining why social media success is difficult to replicate or outsource, using Aaron Levie (CEO of Box) as an example of someone who naturally excels at social media. She emphasizes that effective social media presence typically can't be easily created by hiring an agency - it needs to come naturally to the executive.

speaker: Emily Kramer
text: For PLG I think you want to have a marketer that is responsible for getting people into the product, that's a marketing profile. That's using all of these channels that's driving inbound, that's focused on web conversion, making sure your website converts, that's a marketing skillset. Because it's really likely you have to work with to get this done is really how I think about it.
text_ko: 제품 주도 성장(PLG, Product-Led Growth) 관점에서는 제품으로 사람들을 유입시키는 책임을 질 마케터가 필요하다고 생각해요. 그건 마케팅 역할(marketing profile)이에요. 여러 채널을 활용해 인바운드(inbound)를 만들어내고, 웹 전환(web conversion)에 집중해서 사이트가 실제로 전환되게 만드는 건 마케팅 스킬셋(skillset)이에요. 왜냐하면 이걸 해내려면 누구랑 협업해야 하는지가 제가 생각하는 기준이기 때문이에요.
text_zh: 对于PLG(产品驱动增长)来说，我觉得你需要有个市场人员专门负责把用户拉到产品里来，这就是个营销岗位。要用各种渠道做流量引入，专注网站转化，确保你的网站能转化用户，这些都是营销技能。因为这确实需要你和营销团队配合才能搞定，我就是这么看的。
text_es: Para PLG creo que necesitas tener un marketero que se encargue de meter gente al producto, ese es un perfil de marketing. Que use todos estos canales, que genere tráfico inbound, que se enfoque en la conversión web, asegurándose de que tu sitio web convierta, esas son habilidades de marketing. Porque realmente es muy probable que tengas que trabajar con alguien así para lograr esto, así es como yo lo veo.
context: Lenny asks Emily about whether PLG (product-led growth) companies should hire marketing people or growth PMs for conversion optimization and funnel work. Emily explains that for PLG companies, getting people into the product should be owned by marketing because it requires channel expertise, inbound marketing skills, and web conversion knowledge. She emphasizes that this work requires collaboration with marketing team members who understand websites and inbound strategies.
vocabulary_highlights: marketing profile, driving inbound, web conversion, marketing skillset
topics: Growth & Marketing, Product Management, Starting a Company

speaker: Emily Kramer
text: So I think that product led growth is a misnomer. I think people will do anything they can possibly do not call marketing marketing. I think we always see this. And so I think that product led growth really means not as much sales, which means product plus marketing.
text_ko: 제품 주도 성장(product-led growth)이라는 말은 오히려 잘못된 명칭인 것 같아요. 사람들은 가능한 한 마케팅이라고 안 부르려고 뭐든지 하거든요. 우리는 항상 그런 걸 보죠. 그래서 제품 주도 성장은 사실 영업을 줄인다는 뜻이고, 결국엔 제품과 마케팅(product + marketing)의 결합이에요.
text_zh: 所以我觉得产品驱动增长(product led growth)这个说法其实有问题。我发现大家总是想方设法不把营销叫营销，这种情况我们经常见到。所以我觉得产品驱动增长实际上就是少做点销售，更多地靠产品加营销来做。
text_es: Entonces creo que el crecimiento dirigido por producto (product led growth) es un término equivocado. Creo que la gente hará cualquier cosa que pueda para no llamar al marketing, marketing. Esto lo vemos todo el tiempo. Así que creo que el crecimiento dirigido por producto en realidad significa menos ventas, lo que se traduce en producto más marketing.
context: Lenny asks about the tension between product teams and marketing teams regarding who should own website conversion and growth work in PLG companies. Emily gives her perspective that 'product-led growth' is often just a way to avoid calling marketing work 'marketing.' She argues that PLG really means having less sales involvement, but it still requires both product and marketing working together - it's not purely a product function.
vocabulary_highlights: misnomer, product led growth
topics: Growth & Marketing, Product Management, Strategy & Planning

speaker: Emily Kramer
text: The best marketing teams are impact focus. They can tell you of all the things they're doing, what are the core things that are of driving that linear growth or just keeping the lights on. They can tell you what their big bets are. What are the things that we are doing right now that we believe can cause step change, top of the funnel growth?
text_ko: 최고의 마케팅 팀은 임팩트 중심(impact-focused)이에요. 지금 하는 모든 일들 가운데 무엇이 실제로 선형 성장(linear growth)을 이끌거나 그저 운영을 유지(keeping the lights on)하는 핵심 활동인지 명확히 말할 수 있어요. 또 어떤 게 우리의 큰 베팅(big bets)인지, 지금 하고 있는 일 중에서 단계적 변화(step change)나 퍼널 상단(top of the funnel growth)에서 성장을 만들어낼 수 있다고 믿는 게 무엇인지 분명히 얘기해요.
text_zh: 最好的营销团队都特别注重实际效果。他们能清楚地告诉你，在所有正在做的事情中，哪些是核心的，是推动稳定增长或者维持基本运营的。他们也能告诉你什么是他们的重头戏。就是那些我们现在正在做的，相信能够带来突破性变化、实现漏斗顶端(top of the funnel)大幅增长的事情。
text_es: Los mejores equipos de marketing se enfocan en el impacto real. Te pueden decir de todas las cosas que están haciendo, cuáles son las actividades centrales que impulsan ese crecimiento constante o simplemente mantienen el negocio funcionando. Te pueden decir cuáles son sus grandes apuestas. ¿Cuáles son las cosas que estamos haciendo ahora mismo que creemos que pueden generar un cambio radical, un crecimiento explosivo en la parte alta del embudo (top of the funnel)?
context: Lenny asks Emily what signs indicate that a marketing team is performing well versus poorly, particularly for product managers who might be skeptical of marketing efforts. Emily explains that effective marketing teams are impact-focused rather than doing 'busy work.' She contrasts good teams that can articulate their core growth drivers and big strategic bets versus teams that just throw things at the wall without clear strategy.
vocabulary_highlights: impact focus, keeping the lights on, big bets, step change, top of the funnel
topics: Growth & Marketing, Leadership & Management, Strategy & Planning

speaker: Emily Kramer
text: If our goal is to write 10 blog posts this month. And I'm like, no, that's not a goal, that's maybe a tactic. But the goal should be traffic and the conversion rate from that traffic or the signups that come from that. So you shouldn't have activity goals, you should have impact goals.
text_ko: 만약 이번 달 목표가 블로그 글 10개 쓰기라면요, 전 그건 목표가 아니라 전술(tactic)에 가까운 거라고 생각해요. 진짜 목표는 트래픽(traffic)과 그 트래픽에서 나오는 전환율(conversion rate)이나 그로 인한 회원 가입 수(signups) 같은 성과여야 해요. 그러니까 활동(activity) 목표를 세우지 말고 임팩트(impact) 목표를 세워야 해요.
text_zh: 如果我们的目标是这个月写10篇博客文章，我就会说，不对，这不是目标，这顶多算是个策略手段。真正的目标应该是流量，还有这些流量的转化率(conversion rate)，或者由此带来的注册用户数。所以你不应该设定活动目标，而应该设定影响力目标。
text_es: Si nuestra meta es escribir 10 posts de blog este mes, yo digo: no, eso no es una meta, eso es más bien una táctica. Pero la meta debería ser el tráfico y la tasa de conversión de ese tráfico o los registros que genere. O sea, no deberían tener metas de actividad, sino metas de impacto.
context: Emily continues explaining red flags that indicate a marketing team isn't being effective. She criticizes teams that set activity-based goals like 'write 10 blog posts' instead of outcome-based goals. Emily emphasizes that good marketing teams focus on impact metrics like traffic, conversion rates, and signups rather than just counting activities or outputs.
vocabulary_highlights: activity goals, impact goals
topics: Growth & Marketing, Strategy & Planning, Leadership & Management

speaker: Emily Kramer
text: I think there's a big need for investors that have functional expertise. In traditional VCs. They don't necessarily, maybe they founded companies, maybe they've always been investors or sometimes VC and they really come from sales roles or PM roles. But for me and for marketing and maybe for some of the roles of other people are in, there's not a lot of investors or even advisors from that function and they need help there.
text_ko: 저는 기능적인 전문성을 가진 투자자에 대한 수요가 크다고 생각해요. 전통적인 벤처 캐피탈(VC)에서는 꼭 그런 사람들이 많지 않아요. 어떤 사람들은 회사를 창립했거나, 항상 투자자였거나, 때로는 VC로 일했지만, 주로 영업이나 PM 역할에서 온 경우가 많거든요. 하지만 저와 마케팅, 그리고 다른 역할을 하는 사람들에게는 그 분야에서 활동하는 투자자나 조언자가 많지 않아서 도움이 필요해요.
text_zh: 我觉得市场上很缺那种有具体专业技能的投资人。传统VC(风投)嘛，他们不一定懂，可能创过业，可能一直在做投资，或者有时候是从销售或者PM(产品经理)转过来的。但是对我来说，对于市场营销这块，还有其他一些岗位的人，真的很少有投资人或者顾问是从这些具体职能出身的，但创业者在这些方面又特别需要帮助。
text_es: Creo que hay una gran necesidad de inversionistas que tengan experiencia funcional específica. En los VCs tradicionales, no necesariamente... o sea, a lo mejor fundaron empresas, quizás siempre han sido inversionistas, o a veces son VC que vienen de roles de ventas o de product management (PM). Pero para mí y para marketing, y tal vez para algunos de los roles en los que está otra gente, no hay muchos inversionistas o ni siquiera asesores que vengan de esa función, y ahí es donde necesitan ayuda.
context: Lenny asks Emily for advice on how people can leverage their expertise to become successful angel investors. Emily explains that there's a shortage of investors with deep functional expertise in areas like marketing. She contrasts this with traditional VCs who may have general business experience but lack specific functional knowledge that startups desperately need.
vocabulary_highlights: functional expertise, traditional VCs

speaker: Emily Kramer
text: And we can get into any deal. Which I think as an early angel investor, I'm like, why are people saying it's hard to get into a deal? I don't have this problem. And that's not me tapping myself on the shoulder. It's just showing there's huge shortage here.
text_ko: 우리는 어떤 딜(deal)이든 들어갈 수 있어요. 제가 초기 엔젤 투자자(early angel investor)라서 그런지, 사람들이 '딜에 들어가기 어렵다'고 하는 걸 이해할 수가 없어요. 저는 그런 문제가 전혀 없거든요. 이건 제가 자랑하려는 게 아니라, 단지 여기엔 심각한 부족이 있다는 걸 보여주는 거예요.
text_zh: 而且我们什么项目都能投进去。作为一个早期天使投资人，我就想，为什么大家都说很难找到好项目投资？我从来没遇到过这个问题。我不是在夸自己，这只能说明市场上好的天使投资人真的太稀缺了。
text_es: Y podemos entrar en cualquier operación. Lo cual, pensándolo como inversionista ángel desde el principio, me pregunto: ¿por qué la gente dice que es difícil meterse en un deal? Yo no tengo ese problema. Y no es que me esté echando flores, simplemente demuestra que hay una escasez enorme aquí.
context: Emily continues explaining how to become a successful angel investor by leveraging functional expertise. She shares that having clear, specialized value (helping with marketing) makes it easy to get into competitive deals because there's such a shortage of investors with deep marketing knowledge. She emphasizes this isn't about her personally, but about the market need for specialized expertise.
vocabulary_highlights: get into any deal, tapping myself on the shoulder, huge shortage

speaker: Eoghan McCabe
speaker_expertise: AI/ML Products, Leadership Development, Growth Strategy
text: The first thing I'll say is that CX is deceptively large given it's hidden behind just two words, two letters. Customer experience really is service success, sales and marketing, in my opinion. It's all engagement with all customers. It's the biggest part by headcount of any business.
text_ko: 먼저 드릴 말씀이, 'CX(Customer Experience)'라는 표현이 단 두 단어, 두 글자로 간단하게 보이지만 실제로는 영향력이 훨씬 큰 영역이에요. 제 생각엔 고객 경험은 본질적으로 서비스 성공(service success)이자 영업(sales)과 마케팅(marketing)이에요. 결국 모든 고객과의 모든 상호작용(engagement)이 고객 경험이고요. 어떤 기업을 봐도 인력 규모(headcount)로는 가장 큰 부분이에요.
text_zh: 我先说一点，CX这个概念其实比看起来要大得多，别看就两个字母。在我看来，客户体验(customer experience)实际上就是服务成功、销售和营销的综合体现。说白了就是和所有客户的互动接触。从人员配置上来说，这块儿是任何企业里最大的一个板块。
text_es: Lo primero que te digo es que la experiencia del cliente (CX) es engañosamente amplia para estar escondida detrás de solo dos palabras, dos letras. La experiencia del cliente realmente es el éxito en servicio, ventas y marketing, en mi opinión. Es toda la interacción con todos los clientes. Es la parte más grande por número de empleados de cualquier negocio.
context: Lenny asks about how far AI disruption will extend beyond customer experience (CX), since agents are already transforming Intercom's CX business. Eoghan explains that people underestimate the scope of customer experience - it's not just support, but encompasses service, success, sales, and marketing functions. He emphasizes that CX represents the largest portion of employees in most businesses, making it a massive opportunity for AI transformation.
vocabulary_highlights: deceptively large, hidden behind, by headcount

speaker: Eoghan McCabe
speaker_expertise: AI/ML Products, Leadership Development, Growth Strategy
text: We had just a very comfortable culture as a lot of companies did. There was a lot of focus on social issues and a lot of complaining and dissatisfaction, and I rewrote the values designed to be a sharp knife to cut out the parts of the company that I just knew wouldn't be effective.
text_ko: 저희도 다른 많은 회사들처럼 굉장히 편안하고 안주하는 문화가 있었어요. 사람들은 사회적 이슈에만 신경 쓰고 불평과 불만도 많았죠. 그래서 저는 회사에서 효과가 없을 게 분명한 부분들을 과감히 잘라내는 날카로운 칼이 되도록 핵심가치(values)를 다시 썼어요.
text_zh: 我们以前的企业文化太安逸了，很多公司都这样。大家总是纠结各种社会议题，抱怨这个不满那个的。所以我重新制定了公司价值观，就像用一把锋利的刀子，把那些我知道肯定没效率的部分都切掉。
text_es: Teníamos una cultura muy cómoda como muchas empresas. Había mucho enfoque en temas sociales y muchas quejas e insatisfacción, así que reescribí los valores para que fueran como un cuchillo afilado que cortara las partes de la empresa que yo sabía que no iban a funcionar.
context: Lenny asks about the practical steps Eoghan took to transform Intercom when he returned as CEO. Eoghan explains that the company had developed a comfortable, unfocused culture during his absence. He decided to completely rewrite the company values with the explicit intention of creating cultural change and removing employees who wouldn't thrive in a more demanding, results-oriented environment.
vocabulary_highlights: sharp knife to cut out

speaker: Eoghan McCabe
speaker_expertise: AI/ML Products, Leadership Development, Growth Strategy
text: You don't have a choice. The story of the technology industry or digital technology is really short and it's punctuated by a small number of things, microprocessors, personal computers, the internet, maybe mobile. Now there's AI. I think AI is bigger than all these things. And all of these things disrupted essentially all categories.
text_ko: 선택의 여지가 없어요. 기술 산업이나 디지털 기술의 역사는 사실 굉장히 짧고, 그 짧은 역사에는 몇 가지 큰 사건들—마이크로프로세서(microprocessors), 개인용 컴퓨터(personal computers), 인터넷(the internet), 어쩌면 모바일(mobile)—로 요약돼요. 지금은 인공지능(AI)이 있는 상황이에요. 저는 인공지능이 이 모든 것들보다 영향력이 더 크다고 생각해요. 그리고 이 모든 것들이 사실상 거의 모든 업종을 뒤흔들었어요.
text_zh: 你没有选择的余地。科技行业或者说数字技术的历史其实很短，就是被几个关键节点给划分开的——微处理器、个人电脑、互联网，可能还有移动互联网。现在轮到AI了。我觉得AI比前面这些东西影响都要大。而且这些技术基本上颠覆了所有行业。
text_es: No tienes opción. La historia de la industria tecnológica o la tecnología digital es realmente corta y está marcada por unas pocas cosas clave: los microprocesadores, las computadoras personales, el internet, quizás los móviles. Ahora está la IA. Yo creo que la IA es más grande que todas estas cosas. Y todas estas cosas básicamente revolucionaron todas las categorías.
context: Lenny asks for final advice for founders trying to navigate the AI transformation. Eoghan emphasizes that companies have no choice but to embrace AI, explaining that the technology industry has been shaped by only a few major disruptions throughout history. He argues that AI represents the biggest disruption yet, and like previous technological shifts, it will affect every industry category.
vocabulary_highlights: punctuated by, disrupted essentially all categories

speaker: Eoghan McCabe
speaker_expertise: AI/ML Products, Leadership Development, Growth Strategy
text: So, that was where the 99 cent came from. I always believe that that pricing should come from value and not from costs. The cost is our problem. We just had this sense and intuition early on that this thing will get cheaper and it got a lot cheaper.
text_ko: 그래서 그 99센트가 나온 거예요. 저는 가격은 비용에서 나오는 게 아니라 가치에서 나와야 한다고 늘 믿어요. 비용은 우리가 감당할 문제예요. 초반부터 이게 더 싸질 거라는 직감이 있었고, 실제로 훨씬 싸졌어요.
text_zh: 所以99美分就是这么来的。我一直认为定价应该基于价值，而不是成本。成本是我们自己要解决的问题。我们很早就有这种感觉和直觉，觉得这个东西肯定会越来越便宜，结果确实便宜了很多。
text_es: Entonces, de ahí salió lo de los 99 centavos. Siempre he creído que los precios deben basarse en el valor, no en los costos. El costo es problema nuestro. Desde el principio tuvimos esa sensación y esa intuición de que esto se iba a abaratar, y efectivamente se abarató muchísimo.
context: Lenny asks about Intercom's pricing strategy for Fin, their AI agent that initially cost $1.20 to deliver but was priced at 99 cents per resolved ticket. Eoghan explains their philosophy that pricing should be based on customer value rather than internal costs. Even though they were losing money initially, they believed the underlying AI technology would become more cost-effective over time, which proved correct.
vocabulary_highlights: sense and intuition

speaker: Eoghan McCabe
speaker_expertise: AI/ML Products, Leadership Development, Growth Strategy
text: Great, great therapy and it has to be great, is a recipe for brilliant leadership in my opinion. And then the third part is two years away where I ran away, where I was sick, revenue growth wasn't doing so hot. I unsuccessfully tried to defend myself from a bunch of fake bullshit in the newspapers.
text_ko: 정말 훌륭한 테라피(therapy)는 꼭 필요하고, 제 생각엔 그게 뛰어난 리더십을 만드는 비결이에요. 그리고 세 번째 부분은 제가 도망쳤던 2년간이에요. 그때는 아프기도 했고 매출 성장도 별로였어요. 신문에 실린 온갖 가짜 기사들로부터 저를 방어하려고 했지만 결국 성공하지 못했어요.
text_zh: 我觉得优质的心理治疗，而且必须是真正优质的，这是卓越领导力的秘诀。然后第三个阶段是两年前我逃避的那段时间，当时我状态很差，营收增长也不理想。我还徒劳地试图为自己辩护，应对报纸上那些胡说八道的假新闻。
text_es: Mira, una terapia excelente, y tiene que ser excelente de verdad, es la receta para un liderazgo brillante en mi opinión. Y luego viene la tercera parte, hace dos años cuando me alejé, cuando estaba enfermo, el crecimiento de ingresos no iba nada bien. Traté sin éxito de defenderme de un montón de tonterías falsas en los periódicos.
context: Lenny observes that Eoghan seems very centered and self-reflective, and asks about his personal transformation during the difficult period. Eoghan credits three factors for his growth: startup experience, 12 years of weekly therapy with an exceptional therapist, and surviving a two-year period where he stepped away from the CEO role due to illness and negative press coverage. He argues that quality therapy actually makes leaders more effective, not softer.
vocabulary_highlights: bunch of fake bullshit

speaker: Eoghan McCabe
speaker_expertise: AI/ML Products, Leadership Development, Growth Strategy
text: The abundance of AI is going to make automated things worth zero. Just like the value of cheap content on YouTube. Why do people subscribe to some channels and pay more? Why do people pay to rent movies? Because some things have more quality, more beauty, more craft, more art, more humanity.
text_ko: 인공지능(AI)이 넘쳐나면 자동화된 것들은 가치가 거의 0이 될 거예요. 유튜브의 싸구려 콘텐츠와 같아요. 그런데 왜 사람들은 어떤 채널을 구독하고 더 돈을 낼까요? 왜 사람들은 영화도 돈을 주고 빌려 볼까요? 그건 어떤 것들이 퀄리티가 더 높고, 더 아름답고, 장인정신과 예술성, 인간미가 더 있기 때문이에요.
text_zh: AI的大量涌现会让自动化的东西变得一文不值，就像YouTube上那些廉价内容一样。为什么大家会订阅某些频道，愿意花更多钱呢？为什么人们还会花钱租电影？因为有些东西质量更高，更有美感，更有匠心，更有艺术性，更有人情味儿。
text_es: La abundancia de la inteligencia artificial va a hacer que todo lo automatizado no valga nada. Igual que pasa con el contenido barato en YouTube. ¿Por qué la gente se suscribe a ciertos canales y paga más? ¿Por qué pagan por rentar películas? Porque algunas cosas tienen más calidad, más belleza, más arte, más humanidad.
context: Lenny mentions that Ben Mann from Anthropic predicted that even podcast host jobs like Lenny's will eventually be replaced by AI. Eoghan offers a more optimistic perspective, arguing that while AI will make automated content abundant and cheap, people will still value and pay premium prices for content that has human qualities like beauty, craft, and authentic human stories and perspectives.
vocabulary_highlights: abundance of AI, worth zero

speaker: April Dunford
text: I actually think the first step in a good positioning exercise is to really understand what do we have to position against? So put another way, it's like saying, what do I have to beat in order to win a deal? So in positioning work we call this competitive alternatives. Now, how people mess up this first step is, I say competitive alternatives and they think competition. So things that look exactly like me. But in B2B we kind of have two sets of competitors.
text_ko: 제가 생각하기에 좋은 포지셔닝 작업(positioning exercise)의 첫 번째 단계는 우리가 무엇을 상대해서 포지셔닝해야 하는지를 정말로 이해하는 거예요. 다시 말하면, 거래를 따내기 위해 무엇을 이겨야 하는지, 누구를 이겨야 하는지를 묻는 거죠. 포지셔닝 작업에서는 이를 경쟁 대안(competitive alternatives)이라고 부릅니다. 그런데 사람들이 이 첫 단계를 흔히 잘못 이해하는 건, 제가 '경쟁 대안'이라고 하면 곧장 '경쟁자'—나와 똑같이 보이는 것들—만 떠올린다는 점이에요. 하지만 B2B에서는 사실 경쟁자가 두 가지 종류로 나뉘어요.
text_zh: 我觉得要做好定位(positioning)，第一步其实是要搞清楚我们要对抗什么。换句话说，就是我要打败谁才能拿下这个单子？在定位工作中，我们叫这个"竞争替代方案(competitive alternatives)"。很多人在第一步就搞错了，我一说竞争替代方案，他们就想到竞争对手，就是那些跟我们长得一模一样的公司。但是在B2B里面，其实我们面对两类竞争对手。
text_es: La verdad es que creo que el primer paso en un buen ejercicio de posicionamiento es entender realmente contra qué nos tenemos que posicionar. O sea, dicho de otra manera, es como preguntarse: ¿qué tengo que superar para cerrar un negocio? En el trabajo de posicionamiento a esto le llamamos alternativas competitivas (competitive alternatives). Ahora, donde la gente se equivoca en este primer paso es que digo alternativas competitivas y piensan en competencia directa. O sea, cosas que se parecen exactamente a lo mío. Pero en B2B como que tenemos dos tipos de competidores.
context: Lenny asks April what the first step is for a PM or founder ready to figure out their product's positioning. April explains that before you can position your product, you need to understand what you're competing against - not just direct competitors, but also the status quo (what customers are currently doing to solve the problem). She emphasizes that many companies lose deals to 'no decision' because they fail to position effectively against existing solutions like spreadsheets or manual processes.
vocabulary_highlights: position against, competitive alternatives, mess up this first step, put another way

speaker: Crystal Widjaja
speaker_expertise: Product Strategy, Growth Strategy, B2B SaaS
text: So a lot of people look at tracking data as how do I track my OKR? How do I know if I'm going up or down? But they don't use it to track or identify insights. So I will use the example of using Twitter for, "News" when in reality they're actually using Twitter for entertainment. Do not treat metric gathering as entertainment. It's not there for you to be like, oh, that's interesting, how novel, and then not act on it.
text_ko: 많은 분들이 데이터 추적(tracking data)을 '내 OKR(목표와 핵심 결과)은 어떻게 추적하지? 오르고 있나 내리고 있나?'를 확인하는 용도로만 봐요. 그런데 그걸로 인사이트(insights)를 찾아내거나 식별하는 데는 잘 안 써요. 예를 들어 트위터(Twitter)를 '뉴스'로 쓴다고 생각하지만 사실은 엔터테인먼트(entertainment)로 쓰고 있는 경우가 많습니다. 지표(metric) 수집을 그저 엔터테인먼트(entertainment)처럼 취급하지 마세요. '아, 재밌네, 신기하네' 하고 끝내고 아무 행동도 하지 않는 용도가 아니에요.
text_zh: 很多人看跟踪数据就是为了看自己的OKR(目标与关键结果)怎么样，是在上升还是下降，但他们不会用这些数据去发现洞察。就像很多人说自己上Twitter是为了"看新闻"，实际上就是在娱乐。千万别把收集指标当娱乐，不是让你看了说"哦，挺有意思的，挺新鲜"，然后就没下文了。
text_es: Entonces mucha gente ve los datos de seguimiento como "¿cómo hago tracking de mis OKRs? ¿Cómo sé si voy para arriba o para abajo?" Pero no los usan para identificar insights o sacar conclusiones reales. Te pongo el ejemplo de usar Twitter para "noticias" cuando en realidad lo estás usando para entretenerte. No trates la recopilación de métricas como entretenimiento. No está ahí para que digas "ay, qué interesante, qué curioso" y después no hagas nada al respecto.
context: Lenny asks Crystal about her popular post on why most analytics efforts fail and what teams can do to avoid this. Crystal explains that companies often treat data tracking like entertainment rather than actionable intelligence. She uses the analogy of people claiming they use Twitter for news when they're actually using it for entertainment - similarly, teams look at metrics and find them 'interesting' but don't change their behavior based on the insights.
vocabulary_highlights: how novel, metric gathering, track or identify insights

speaker: Julie Zhou
speaker_expertise: Product Design, User Experience, Leadership Development
text: But looking back, I think it probably took me about seven or eight years until I became a little bit more comfortable with that. After seven or eight years I could look back, I could see all of the things that I got to work on, I could see all the ways that I had grown and learned in that experience. And something clicked for me where I realized it's kind of two sides of the same coin.
text_ko: 돌이켜보면, 그게 조금 편해지기까지 아마 7~8년 정도 걸린 것 같아요. 7~8년쯤 지나서야 제가 해온 일들을 돌아볼 수 있었고, 그 경험을 통해 얼마나 성장하고 배웠는지도 보이기 시작했어요. 그러다 어느 순간 모든 게 딱 맞춰지면서 결국 그건 같은 동전의 양면이라는 걸 깨달았어요.
text_zh: 不过回头看，我觉得大概花了七八年时间吧，才对这件事稍微适应一些。七八年之后回过头来看，我能看到自己参与过的所有那些项目，也能看到自己在这个过程中各种各样的成长和收获。然后突然就开窍了，意识到这其实是一个硬币的两面。
text_es: Pero mirándolo ahora, creo que me tomó como siete u ocho años hasta que me empecé a sentir más cómodo con eso. Después de esos siete u ocho años pude ver hacia atrás, pude ver todas las cosas en las que había trabajado, todas las formas en las que había crecido y aprendido en esa experiencia. Y ahí fue cuando me cayó el veinte de que en realidad son dos caras de la misma moneda.
context: Lenny asks Julie about her rapid rise from designer to VP of design at Facebook and what advice she has for early career professionals. Julie reflects on how she felt like an imposter for seven to eight years at Facebook, constantly questioning whether she deserved her position. She explains that over time she realized that feeling uncomfortable and unprepared often coincides with the fastest periods of career growth - it's two sides of the same coin.
vocabulary_highlights: two sides of the same coin, something clicked for me

speaker: Shishir Mehrotra
speaker_expertise: Engineering Leadership, Growth Strategy, Team Building
text: I have an interview question I ask, it's a very simple question and it's a coded Eigenquestions test. And the question is, a group of scientists have invented a teleportation device. They've hired you, Lenny, to be they're sort of business counterpart, bring this to market, product [inaudible] this question actually worked well for [inaudible]. But say, you could be the product manager for this thing, bring it to market. What do you do?
text_ko: 제가 면접에서 자주 묻는 질문이 하나 있어요. 아주 단순한 질문인데 코드화된 Eigenquestions 테스트(Eigenquestions test)에요. 질문은 이래요. 과학자 그룹이 순간이동 장치(teleportation device)를 발명했어요. 그리고 레니(Lenny)를 비즈니스 쪽 파트너로 고용해서 이걸 시장에 내놓으라고 했다고 해요. 제품 관리자(product manager)가 돼서 이걸 시장에 출시한다면, 당신은 어떻게 하시겠어요?
text_zh: 我有个面试问题，很简单的一个问题，其实是个隐性特征测试(coded Eigenquestions test)。问题是这样的：有一群科学家发明了一个传送装置，他们雇你来做商业合作伙伴，负责把这个产品推向市场。假设你就是这个产品的产品经理，要把它推向市场，你会怎么做？
text_es: Tengo una pregunta que siempre hago en entrevistas, es muy sencilla y en realidad es una prueba codificada de Eigenquestions. La pregunta es así: imagínate que un grupo de científicos ha inventado un dispositivo de teletransportación. Te han contratado a ti, Lenny, para ser como su contraparte de negocios, para llevar esto al mercado, ser el product manager... esta pregunta en realidad me ha funcionado muy bien. Pero digamos, tú podrías ser el product manager de esto, llevarlo al mercado. ¿Qué harías?
context: Lenny asks Shishir about his interview techniques and frameworks for evaluating talent. Shishir describes his favorite interview question which tests a candidate's ability to identify 'eigenquestions' - the most important questions that unlock the core understanding needed to make decisions. He gives candidates a hypothetical scenario about commercializing a teleportation device, then limits them to asking only two questions before creating a business plan.
vocabulary_highlights: coded Eigenquestions test, business counterpart, bring this to market

speaker: Kristen Berman
speaker_expertise: Marketing Strategy, User Experience, Product Management
text: There are so many mistakes that humans make and we can call them biases, heuristics, our team uses psychologies. What are the psychologies that drive us? And so to tackle this, our team basically has created a model of behavior change we call the three Bs. And this summarizes the most important psychologies that drive user that are important to the product managers and the marketers.
text_ko: 사람들이 저지르는 실수들이 정말 많은데, 우리는 그걸 편향(biases)이나 휴리스틱(heuristics)이라고도 하고, 우리 팀은 보통 심리(psychologies)라는 표현을 써요. 그럼 도대체 우리를 움직이는 심리들은 뭘까요? 그래서 이를 해결하려고 우리 팀은 행동 변화 모델(model of behavior change)을 만들었고, 그걸 세 가지 B(Three Bs)라고 불러요. 이 모델은 제품 관리자와 마케터에게 중요한, 사용자를 움직이는 핵심 심리들을 요약한 거예요.
text_zh: 人类会犯很多错误，我们可以叫它们偏见、启发式思维，我们团队叫它们心理因素。到底是什么心理因素在驱动我们呢？为了解决这个问题，我们团队基本上创建了一个行为改变模型，我们叫它"三个B"。这个模型总结了驱动用户的最重要的心理因素，对产品经理和市场营销人员来说特别重要。
text_es: Hay muchísimos errores que cometemos los humanos y los podemos llamar sesgos, heurísticas, nuestro equipo usa el término "psicologías". ¿Cuáles son las psicologías que nos impulsan? Y para abordar esto, nuestro equipo básicamente creó un modelo de cambio de comportamiento que llamamos las tres Bs. Y esto resume las psicologías más importantes que impulsan al usuario y que son clave para los product managers y los de marketing.
context: Lenny asks Kristen about using behavioral science to improve products. Kristen introduces her team's framework called the 'three Bs' for understanding behavioral change. This model summarizes the key psychological drivers that influence user behavior and is designed specifically for product managers and marketers. The framework has been implemented at major companies like Google, Microsoft, and LinkedIn to help teams systematically apply behavioral science principles.
vocabulary_highlights: biases, heuristics, psychologies that drive us, to tackle this

speaker: Elena Verna
text: I think every single company has to first focus on being product led and retention, period. The only way that you will ever have any chance of acquisition being product led is if you nail your product led retention. Let me break it down. Retention falls into two main KPIs, which is activation and then engagement.
text_ko: 제 생각에는 모든 회사가 먼저 제품 주도(product-led)와 고객 유지(retention)에 집중해야 해요. 그게 핵심이에요. 제품 주도(product-led)로 고객 획득(acquisition)을 하려면 제품 주도형 유지(product-led retention)를 확실히 잡아야 해요. 좀 더 풀어 설명할게요. 유지(retention)는 두 가지 핵심 성과 지표(KPI)로 나뉘는데, 하나는 활성화(activation), 다른 하나는 참여(engagement)이에요.
text_zh: 我觉得每家公司都必须先专注于产品驱动(product led)和留存，没得商量。只有你把产品驱动的留存做到位了，你的获客(acquisition)才有可能也做到产品驱动。我给你拆解一下。留存主要看两个关键指标(KPI)，一个是激活(activation)，另一个是用户参与度(engagement)。
text_es: Mira, yo creo que todas las empresas, sin excepción, tienen que enfocarse primero en ser product led y en la retención, punto. La única manera de que tengas alguna posibilidad de que tu adquisición sea product led es si claves completamente tu retención product led. Te lo explico mejor. La retención se divide en dos KPIs principales: la activación y después el engagement.
context: Lenny discusses B2B growth strategies with Elena, who is head of growth at Amplitude and considered one of the top experts in B2B growth. Elena explains her fundamental principle that companies must master product-led retention before attempting product-led acquisition. She breaks down retention into activation and engagement, arguing that without habitual user engagement, there's no foundation for users to refer others or create content that attracts new users.
vocabulary_highlights: product led, nail your product led retention, let me break it down

speaker: Shreyas Doshi
text: All your tasks are not created equal. There are actually three type of tasks that you end up doing in such a role. So there are L tasks, which are leverage tasks. And the L tasks are such that when you put in a certain amount of effort, you get 10X or 100X in return in terms of impact. So those are L tasks, leverage tasks.
text_ko: 모든 업무가 똑같이 만들어진 건 아니에요. 사실 그런 역할에서는 하게 되는 업무가 세 가지 유형으로 나뉘어요. 그중 하나가 L 작업(L tasks), 즉 레버리지 작업(leverage tasks)인데요. 이런 L 작업은 일정한 노력을 들이면 영향력이 10배(10X)나 100배(100X)로 돌아오는 업무예요.
text_zh: 你的所有任务其实是不一样的。在这种职位上，你做的任务实际上分三种类型。有一种叫L类任务，就是杠杆任务(leverage tasks)。这种L类任务的特点就是，你投入一定的精力，能获得10倍甚至100倍的回报和影响力。这就是L类任务，杠杆任务(leverage tasks)。
text_es: No todas las tareas son iguales. En realidad hay tres tipos de tareas que acabas haciendo en este tipo de rol. Están las tareas L, que son las tareas de apalancamiento (leverage tasks). Y las tareas L son aquellas donde cuando pones cierto esfuerzo, obtienes 10 veces o 100 veces más de retorno en términos de impacto. Esas son las tareas L, las tareas de apalancamiento (leverage tasks).
context: Lenny asks Shreyas about productivity frameworks for product managers. Shreyas introduces his LNO framework, which he developed after experiencing overwhelming stress early in his Google career. He explains that not all tasks provide equal return on investment - L tasks (leverage) give 10X or 100X impact, N tasks (neutral) give roughly 1:1 return, and O tasks (overhead) give less return than the effort invested. The key insight is that most people treat all tasks the same way, leading to burnout and inefficiency.
vocabulary_highlights: not created equal, leverage tasks, 10X or 100X in return

speaker: Eric Ries
text: People act like having a startup fail is the worst thing that can happen to you. And man, that's not even in the top 10. It's bad, I've done it, it's awful. It's really bad, but far worse is to be in a company that won't die, a zombie, undead company that you hate, but you can't leave. Oof, have I met people like that, and we're having a mental health crisis among founders that's not talked about enough.
text_ko: 사람들이 마치 스타트업(startup)이 망하는 게 인생 최악인 것처럼 말해요. 근데 솔직히 그건 최악 10위권에도 안 들어요. 물론 나쁘죠 — 저도 겪어봤고 정말 끔찍했어요. 그런데 훨씬 더 심한 건 도무지 끝나지 않는 회사, 즉 좀비 회사(zombie company)에 갇혀 있는 거예요. 그 회사를 진짜 싫어하는데도 떠날 수가 없는 상황이요. 아, 그런 사람들 정말 많이 만났어요. 창업자들(founders) 사이에 정신 건강 위기(mental health crisis)가 오고 있는데 이 얘기는 충분히 안 되고 있어요.
text_zh: 大家总觉得创业失败是天塌下来的事儿，哥们儿，这连前十都排不上。确实很糟心，我经历过，真的很难受。但更要命的是待在一个死不了的公司里，就像僵尸企业一样，你恨死了但又走不了。天哪，我见过太多这样的人了，创始人的心理健康危机真的没有得到足够重视。
text_es: La gente actúa como si tener una startup que fracase fuera lo peor que te puede pasar. Y hermano, eso ni siquiera está en el top 10. Está cabrón, lo he vivido, es horrible. Está muy mal, pero mucho peor es estar en una empresa que no se muere, una empresa zombie, muerta en vida que odias, pero no puedes irte. Uff, he conocido gente así, y tenemos una crisis de salud mental entre fundadores de la que no se habla lo suficiente.
context: Lenny asks Eric about his career and current work. Eric reflects on the mental health challenges facing entrepreneurs and different types of business failures. He explains that while startup failure is painful, being trapped in a 'zombie' company that won't die but also won't succeed is far worse for founders' wellbeing. Eric emphasizes the often-overlooked psychological toll of building companies that become forces founders no longer believe in.
vocabulary_highlights: zombie, undead company, mental health crisis, so-called successes, find abhorrent
topics: Starting a Company, Work-Life Balance, Decision Making

speaker: Eric Ries
text: And I would go and have these meetings, and I'm not making this up, people would yell at me in the meeting. I would get yelled at. In fact, I would be asked not very kindly to leave, and I'd be like, "I don't understand. What are you yelling... Why are you mad at me? You asked me for this meeting." And they'd be like... I'm just telling you what I witnessed with my own eyes. We at IMVU, we shipped product 50 times a day on average at a time when people were lucky to be doing it monthly if they were really advanced.
text_ko: 그리고 그런 회의에 제가 가면, 이건 제가 꾸며낸 얘기가 아니에요. 회의에서 사람들이 저한테 소리를 지르곤 했어요. 심지어 별로 친절하게 나가라고 하기도 했고요. 저는 "무슨 소리인지 모르겠어요. 왜 저한테 화를 내세요? 이 회의를 요청하신 분들이잖아요" 이렇게 말하곤 했어요. 사람들이 뭐라고 하냐면… 저는 그냥 제 눈으로 직접 본 걸 말하는 거예요. 저희 IMVU는 그때 평균 하루에 제품을 하루에 50번씩 배포(ship)했어요. 그때 다른 회사들은, 정말 앞선 곳조차 운이 좋아야 한 달에 한 번 정도 했던 시절이었죠.
text_zh: 我就去参加这些会议，我没瞎说啊，会上真有人冲我吼。就是有人对我大喊大叫。甚至还有人很不客气地让我滚蛋，我就懵了，"我搞不懂啊，你吼什么...你干嘛对我发火？明明是你要求开这个会的。" 然后他们就...我说的都是我亲眼看到的。我们IMVU那会儿，平均一天发布产品50次，要知道那个年代，别人能做到一个月发布一次就算很牛了。
text_es: Y yo iba a esas reuniones, y no me lo estoy inventando, la gente me gritaba en plena junta. Me gritaban de verdad. De hecho, me pedían no muy amablemente que me fuera, y yo me quedaba como "No entiendo. ¿Por qué me están gritando...? ¿Por qué están enojados conmigo? Ustedes me pidieron esta reunión." Y ellos como que... Solo les estoy contando lo que vi con mis propios ojos. Nosotros en IMVU, lanzábamos producto 50 veces al día en promedio, en una época donde la gente tenía suerte si lo hacía mensualmente, y eso si eran realmente avanzados.
context: Lenny asks Eric about his early career and how he didn't expect to have such impact on startup culture. Eric describes the early days before Lean Startup became popular, when he would meet with VCs and startup teams to share his engineering methods. His practices of shipping code 50 times per day seemed impossible to most people at the time, leading to hostile reactions in meetings where people literally asked him to leave.
vocabulary_highlights: not very kindly, witnessed with my own eyes, really advanced, shipped product
topics: Product Management, Leadership & Management, Learning & Growth

speaker: Eric Ries
text: We charge onto the field and no other army ever came to charge us back, just we won by default because the people who were doing it the old way didn't really like it or want... It was very few defenders of the old way. There were very few people who came out and said, "Actually, no, Stage-Gate is actually still the correct product idea. You've got it wrong." It never happened.
text_ko: 우리가 전장으로 뛰어들었는데 아무도 우리를 다시 공격하러 오지 않았어요. 그래서 그냥 자동으로 이긴 셈이었어요. 옛 방식으로 하던 사람들은 사실 그 방식을 별로 좋아하지도, 원하지도 않았거든요. 옛 방식을 지키려던 방어자는 거의 없었어요. "아니에요, 스테이지-게이트(Stage-Gate)가 여전히 옳은 제품 아이디어예요. 당신들이 틀렸어요."라고 선뜻 나선 사람은 정말 드물었고 그런 일은 일어나지 않았어요.
text_zh: 我们冲到战场上，结果根本没有其他队伍来跟我们对抗，就这样不战而胜了，因为那些还在用老方法的人其实心里也不太认同，也不想继续那样做...为旧方式辩护的人真的很少很少。基本上没什么人站出来说"不对，阶段门(Stage-Gate)流程才是正确的产品开发思路，你们搞错了。"这种情况压根就没发生过。
text_es: Nos lanzamos al campo de batalla y nunca apareció otro ejército que nos hiciera frente, simplemente ganamos por descarte porque la gente que hacía las cosas a la antigua no estaba realmente convencida o no quería... Había muy pocos defensores del método tradicional. Muy poca gente salió a decirnos "No, esperen, el modelo Stage-Gate sigue siendo la forma correcta de manejar las ideas de producto. Ustedes están equivocados." Eso nunca pasó.
context: Lenny asks about the current state of the Lean Startup movement. Eric explains how he expected the movement to face fierce opposition from traditional business methodologies, using a military metaphor to describe the anticipated 'battle of ideas.' However, he was surprised to discover there were very few people defending old product development approaches like Stage-Gate methodology - the victory came by default rather than through intellectual combat.
vocabulary_highlights: charge onto the field, won by default, defenders of the old way, Stage-Gate
topics: Product Management, Strategy & Planning, Learning & Growth

speaker: Eric Ries
text: I wrote an article, God, five or 10 years ago. God, I can't even remember how many years ago now. It was like Top Misconceptions About Lean Startup, and it was like, "Number one, lean means cheap, so if you're doing Lean Startup, it means you're not raising money." And it's like, "That's not true." And then kind of I remember what they are... And they're all still prevalent, nothing's changed. I could write that same article today.
text_ko: 와, 한 5년 아니면 10년쯤 전에 글을 썼어요. 지금 몇 년 전인지도 기억이 안 나네요. '린 스타트업(Lean Startup)에 대한 가장 큰 오해들' 같은 글이었는데, 첫 번째가 '린(lean)은 저렴하다는 뜻이라 린 스타트업(Lean Startup)을 하면 투자를 안 받는다'는 거였어요. 근데 그건 사실이 아니에요. 다른 오해들도 뭐였는지 기억나고… 근데 그 모든 오해가 아직도 널리 퍼져 있고 달라진 게 하나도 없어요. 오늘도 똑같은 글을 쓸 수 있을 것 같아요.
text_zh: 我记得我写过一篇文章，天哪，大概是五年前还是十年前吧。天哪，我现在都记不清到底是多少年前了。那篇文章叫《关于精益创业(Lean Startup)的几大误区》之类的，第一条就是"精益就等于省钱，所以如果你在做精益创业(Lean Startup)，就意味着你不打算融资。"然后我就说，"这完全不对。"我大概还记得其他几条是什么...现在这些误区还是到处都是，一点都没变。我今天写同样的文章内容都不用改。
text_es: Escribí un artículo hace, Dios, cinco o diez años. Dios, ya ni me acuerdo de hace cuántos años. Era algo como "Los principales mitos sobre Lean Startup", y decía: "Número uno, lean significa barato, entonces si estás haciendo Lean Startup, significa que no estás levantando capital." Y yo decía: "Eso no es cierto." Y más o menos me acuerdo de cuáles eran... Y todos siguen ahí, no ha cambiado nada. Podría escribir ese mismo artículo hoy.
