context: Lenny asks Eric about misconceptions regarding Lean Startup that frustrate him most. Eric recalls writing an article years ago addressing common misunderstandings about his methodology. The biggest misconception is that 'lean' means 'cheap' and that Lean Startup companies shouldn't raise venture capital. He expresses frustration that despite years of clarification, these same misconceptions persist unchanged in the startup community.
vocabulary_highlights: prevalent, nothing's changed, misconceptions
topics: Starting a Company, Fundraising, Communication Skills

speaker: Eric Ries
text: But the thing that gets missed from the story is that Facebook's already started at that point, it's already being successful, and they're on the break between semesters on the summer. And Dustin Moskovitz, and Mark Zuckerberg, and Adam D'Angelo, and I forget who else are living in this house together. Someone told me this story about what they were actually working on at that time. It wasn't Facebook.
text_ko: 그 이야기에서 사람들이 잘 놓치는 건, 그때쯤엔 이미 페이스북이 시작돼서 성공하고 있던 시점이라는 거예요. 게다가 그들은 여름 방학 중이었고, 더스틴 모스코비츠, 마크 저커버그, 아담 디앤젤로, 그리고 누가 더 있었는지 잘 기억은 안 나지만 다 같이 한 집에서 살고 있었어요. 누군가가 그들이 실제로 그때 뭘 하고 있었는지에 대해 얘기해줬는데, 그건 페이스북이 아니었어요.
text_zh: 但是大家都忽略了一个关键点，就是那时候Facebook其实已经起步了，而且已经做得挺成功的，当时正好是暑假放假期间。然后Dustin Moskovitz、Mark Zuckerberg、Adam D'Angelo，还有其他几个人，我忘了是谁了，反正他们就住在一个房子里。有人跟我说了个故事，讲他们那时候真正在忙什么。结果不是Facebook。
text_es: Pero lo que se pierde en esa historia es que Facebook ya había empezado en ese momento, ya estaba funcionando bien, y estaban en las vacaciones de verano entre semestres. Y Dustin Moskovitz, Mark Zuckerberg, Adam D'Angelo, y no me acuerdo quién más estaban viviendo juntos en esa casa. Alguien me contó esta historia sobre en qué estaban trabajando realmente en ese momento. No era Facebook.
context: Lenny asks about pivoting and how common it is for startups to change direction completely. Eric shares a lesser-known Facebook story to illustrate how even successful founders can miss recognizing their breakthrough products. He describes how Mark Zuckerberg and his co-founders were living in Palo Alto during summer break, working on other projects instead of Facebook, even though Facebook was already showing success - demonstrating how difficult it can be to recognize when you've found product-market fit.
vocabulary_highlights: gets missed from the story, break between semesters, actually working on
topics: Starting a Company, Decision Making, Strategy & Planning

speaker: Eric Ries
text: So first of all, if you're asking whether you should pivot or not you probably know the answer already. That's the first thing to just straight up say. People call me sometimes they're like "I want to know if I have product market fit." Well, the fact that you have time to call me and ask me this question already tells me the answer. If you have had product-market fit you would not have time for this.
text_ko: 먼저, 피벗(pivot)을 해야 할지 말아야 할지 묻고 계시다면 아마 스스로 이미 답을 알고 계실 거예요. 그걸 솔직히 말하는 게 먼저예요. 가끔 저한테 전화하시는 분들이 "제품-시장 적합성(product-market fit)이 있는지 알고 싶다"고 해요. 그런데 저에게 전화를 걸어 이런 질문을 할 시간 자체가 있다는 사실만으로도 답이 드러나요. 진짜로 제품-시장 적합성이 있었다면 이런 질문을 할 시간이 없었을 거예요.
text_zh: 首先啊，如果你在纠结要不要转型(pivot)，其实你心里已经有答案了。这话我得直说。有时候有人打电话给我说"我想知道我们是不是已经找到了产品市场契合度(product market fit)"。其实你有时间打电话问我这个问题，就已经说明答案了。如果你真的找到了产品市场契合度(product market fit)，你根本没时间打这个电话。
text_es: Primero que nada, si te estás preguntando si deberías hacer un pivot o no, probablemente ya sabes la respuesta. Eso es lo primero que hay que decir de frente. A veces me llama gente y me dice "quiero saber si tengo product-market fit". Bueno, el hecho de que tengas tiempo para llamarme y preguntarme esto ya me dice la respuesta. Si realmente tuvieras product-market fit, no tendrías tiempo ni para esto.
context: Lenny asks Eric for tactical advice on how founders should decide whether to pivot or stay the course, especially relevant for struggling startups. Eric provides a blunt reality check: if founders have time to contemplate whether they should pivot, they probably already know they need to. He explains that true product-market fit creates such overwhelming demand and urgency that founders don't have time for philosophical discussions - they're too busy handling growth.
vocabulary_highlights: straight up say, already tells me the answer, had product-market fit
topics: Starting a Company, Decision Making, Product Management

speaker: Eric Ries
text: The aperture of possible futures that AI makes possible is so incredibly wide. And Predicting it requires a really deep understanding of a bunch of empirical questions, as far as I can tell, nobody knows the answers to right now. So given that it's not knowable what's going to happen... You're not an expert enough. As far as I can tell nobody knows. The people who are most expert are actively doing the research to try to find out the thing that will help us predict.
text_ko: AI가 열어주는 가능한 미래의 폭(aperture)은 정말 어마어마하게 넓어요. 그걸 예측하려면 여러 경험적 질문들(empirical questions)에 대해 아주 깊이 이해해야 하고, 제 판단으로는 지금은 아무도 그 답을 모르는 것 같아요. 그래서 앞으로 무슨 일이 일어날지 알 수 없다면, 당신은 아직 충분한 전문가가 아니에요. 가장 전문적인 사람들은 바로 예측에 도움이 될 요소를 찾아내기 위해 활발히 연구하고 있어요.
text_zh: AI带来的未来可能性简直太广了，广得不可思议。要想预测这些，你得对一大堆实际问题有非常深入的理解，但据我所知，现在没人知道这些问题的答案。既然无法预知会发生什么...你还不够专业。据我了解，没人真正知道。那些最专业的人也在积极做研究，试图找到能帮我们做预测的东西。
text_es: La gama de futuros posibles que abre la IA es increíblemente amplia. Y predecir todo esto requiere un entendimiento muy profundo de un montón de cuestiones empíricas que, por lo que veo, nadie sabe responder ahora mismo. Entonces, dado que no se puede saber qué va a pasar... no eres lo suficientemente experto. Por lo que puedo ver, nadie lo sabe. Las personas que más saben del tema están justamente haciendo la investigación para tratar de encontrar lo que nos ayude a predecir.
context: Lenny asks about how AI is changing the lean startup approach and product development. Eric addresses the uncertainty many people feel about AI's impact on business and society. He explains his framework for taking ethical action despite not knowing what the future holds - the range of possible AI outcomes is so vast that even experts are still researching fundamental questions, so individuals shouldn't feel paralyzed by their lack of expertise.
vocabulary_highlights: aperture of possible futures, empirical questions, not knowable, actively doing the research
topics: Strategy & Planning, Decision Making, Learning & Growth

speaker: Eric Simons
speaker_expertise: AI/ML Products, Growth Strategy, Engineering Leadership
text: I think that's the hard thing about being an entrepreneur. There are periods of time where you have to make judgment calls that are not going to be the consensus view. You got to have confidence in your convictions on how to best play the hand.
text_ko: 그게 창업가(entrepreneur)로 사는 가장 힘든 점인 것 같아요. 어떤 때는 대다수의 의견(consensus view)과 다른 판단(judgment calls)을 내려야 할 때가 있어요. 그럴 때는 주어진 상황을 어떻게 가장 잘 풀어갈지에 대한 내 신념(convictions)을 믿고 자신감을 가져야 해요.
text_zh: 我觉得做创业者最难的就是，有时候你得做一些决定，而这些决定大家可能都不认同。你必须对自己的判断有信心，知道怎么把手里的牌打好。
text_es: Creo que eso es lo más difícil de ser emprendedor. Hay momentos en los que tienes que tomar decisiones que no van a ser del agrado de todos. Tienes que tener confianza en tus convicciones sobre cómo jugar mejor tus cartas.
context: Lenny asks Eric about the counterintuitive lessons from StackBlitz's journey, particularly building technology first and then finding a problem to solve later. Eric explains how during the 2020-2021 period when companies were pressured to grow rapidly and increase headcount, StackBlitz chose to remain conservative with their burn rate and team size. He emphasizes that entrepreneurs must sometimes make decisions that go against popular opinion at the time.
vocabulary_highlights: consensus view, confidence in your convictions, play the hand
topics: Leadership & Management, Decision Making, Starting a Company

speaker: Eric Simons
speaker_expertise: AI/ML Products, Growth Strategy, Engineering Leadership
text: It was kind of like, Bolt's this overnight success, seven years in the making.
text_ko: 뭔가 그랬어요. Bolt가 하룻밤 사이에 뜬 것처럼 보이지만, 사실은 7년을 공들여 만든 성공이에요.
text_zh: 这就像是说，Bolt是个一夜成名的公司，但其实背后默默耕耘了七年。
text_es: Fue algo así como que Bolt se convirtió en un éxito de la noche a la mañana, pero que en realidad le tomó siete años construir.
context: Lenny discusses how people often don't see the years of work that preceded Bolt's explosive growth. Eric acknowledges this perception paradox - while Bolt appears to be an instant hit that went from zero to massive revenue in months, it was actually built on seven years of developing the underlying WebContainer technology at StackBlitz. This phrase captures the reality that many 'sudden' successes are actually the result of long periods of preparation and groundwork.
vocabulary_highlights: overnight success, in the making

speaker: Eric Simons
speaker_expertise: AI/ML Products, Growth Strategy, Engineering Leadership
text: Most importantly, it's been the people. It's rare to find startups where you have the core group of five, six, seven people that have been there for five years plus.
text_ko: 무엇보다 사람들 덕분이었어요. 다섯, 여섯, 일곱 명 정도의 핵심 멤버가 5년 넘게 함께한 스타트업은 찾기 정말 드물어요.
text_zh: 最关键的还是人，真的很难得能找到一个创业公司，核心团队五六个人、六七个人能一起干五年以上的。
text_es: Lo más importante ha sido la gente. Es muy difícil encontrar startups donde tengas un grupo central de cinco, seis, siete personas que lleven ahí más de cinco años.
context: Lenny asks how StackBlitz managed to grow so rapidly with such a small team of about 20 people. Eric explains that their success stems from having a stable core team that has worked together for over five years, which is uncommon in Silicon Valley where people typically stay at startups for only one or two years. This stability allowed them to take long-term bets and maintain high levels of trust and context across the team.
vocabulary_highlights: core group, five years plus

speaker: Eric Simons
speaker_expertise: AI/ML Products, Growth Strategy, Engineering Leadership
text: There's some amount of, there's feedback from the customers of, 'This thing didn't taste good.' And then there's like, 'Hey, we've been cooking something interesting, and this tastes... I don't know. This, I think you're going to like this. I think this is a killer dish.' And so you kind of have to balance those things.
text_ko: 고객들한테서 '이건 맛이 별로였어'라는 피드백도 있고, 반면에는 '우리가 뭔가 흥미로운 걸 만들었는데, 이건… 글쎄. 근데 넌 이거 좋아할 거야. 진짜 킬러 요리(killer dish)야'라고 내부에서 열광하는 경우도 있어요. 그래서 그런 것들 사이에서 균형을 잘 맞춰야 해요.
text_zh: 客户会给我们反馈说"这个东西不好吃"。但同时我们也会想"嘿，我们正在研发一些有意思的东西，这个味道...怎么说呢，我觉得你们会喜欢的，我觉得这绝对是个爆款产品"。所以你得在这两者之间找个平衡。
text_es: Hay cierta cantidad de feedback de los clientes que dicen "Esto no sabía bien." Pero también está el "Oye, hemos estado cocinando algo interesante, y esto sabe... no sé. Esto, creo que te va a encantar. Creo que este plato va a arrasar." Entonces tienes que equilibrar esas dos cosas.
context: Lenny asks about how StackBlitz prioritizes features given the overwhelming number of requests from their million monthly active users. Eric uses a restaurant chef analogy to explain their approach to product development. He describes the balance between responding to direct customer feedback about problems versus proactively building new capabilities that customers haven't explicitly requested but that the team believes will be valuable.
vocabulary_highlights: killer dish, balance those things

speaker: Eric Simons
speaker_expertise: AI/ML Products, Growth Strategy, Engineering Leadership
text: And I think it's actually, largely, a function of just years of experience doing it. I think if you kind of rewound 10 years ago, I would have had really no, I wouldn't have had just the years of getting my butt kicked by the free market, to have cultivated a sense of this stuff.
text_ko: 사실 이건 대부분 그냥 오랜 시간 직접 해오면서 쌓인 경험의 결과예요. 10년 전으로 되돌려놓으면 솔직히 전혀 그럴 수 없었을 거예요. 자유시장(free market)에서 얻어맞아가며 쌓은 시간이 없었으니까요.
text_zh: 我觉得这主要就是多年实战经验积累出来的。你想啊，要是倒回十年前，我根本就没有这种感觉，毕竟还没有被自由市场摩擦那么多年，也就培养不出这种嗅觉来。
text_es: Y creo que en realidad es, en gran parte, cuestión de años de experiencia haciéndolo. Creo que si regresáramos 10 años atrás, yo no habría tenido, simplemente no habría tenido esos años de que el mercado libre me diera una paliza tras otra, para haber desarrollado un sentido para estas cosas.
context: Eric continues explaining how he decides what features to prioritize at StackBlitz. He reflects on how product intuition develops over time through experience. Eric acknowledges that his ability to make good product decisions comes from years of trial and error in the startup world, where the market has repeatedly tested and refined his judgment about what customers actually want versus what they say they want.
vocabulary_highlights: getting my butt kicked by, free market, cultivated a sense

speaker: Eric Simons
speaker_expertise: AI/ML Products, Growth Strategy, Engineering Leadership
text: And when you think about, 'Okay, how would you best interact with an AI developer agent?' It's basically that. You really want to be good at defining scope, and helping it go and debug various things, or whatever have you. There's a huge overlap of the skill set of being a rock star PM, and being really good at using, frankly, any of these text to apps or Cogen tools.
text_ko: 그리고 '자, AI 개발자 에이전트(AI developer agent)랑 어떻게 가장 잘 상호작용할까?'라고 생각해보면, 사실 핵심은 그거예요. 범위를 잘 정의하고, 에이전트가 가서 여기저기서 문제를 찾아 디버깅하게 도와줄 줄 알아야 해요. 스타 PM(rock star PM)이 갖춘 스킬셋과, 솔직히 말하면 이런 텍스트-투-앱(text to apps)이나 코겐 도구(Cogen tools)를 잘 다루는 능력은 많은 부분이 겹쳐요.
text_zh: 你想想，"怎么跟AI开发助手最好地配合呢？" 其实就是这样。你得擅长定义范围，帮它去调试各种问题什么的。做一个超牛的PM(产品经理)需要的技能，和熟练使用这些文本转应用工具或者代码生成(Cogen)工具需要的技能，基本上是重叠的。
text_es: Y cuando lo piensas, "Bueno, ¿cuál sería la mejor manera de interactuar con un agente desarrollador de IA?" Básicamente es eso. Realmente necesitas ser bueno definiendo el alcance del proyecto, y ayudándolo a debuggear varias cosas, o lo que sea que necesites. Hay una coincidencia enorme entre las habilidades de ser un PM estrella, y ser realmente bueno usando, la verdad, cualquiera de estas herramientas de texto a apps o de Cogen.
context: Eric discusses the limitations of Bolt and explains who tends to be most successful with the tool. He notes that the most successful non-developer users are typically product managers because they already possess skills that translate well to working with AI coding tools. Eric argues that PMs' expertise in defining project scope and directing developers makes them naturally good at prompting and guiding AI agents to build software effectively.
vocabulary_highlights: defining scope, rock star PM, huge overlap

speaker: Ethan Evans
speaker_expertise: Executive Coaching, Leadership Development, Product Strategy
text: Two hours is great, but you only need two hours once a month. People think invention takes all this time. The thing is once you have one good idea, it often takes years to express that.
text_ko: 두 시간은 충분해요. 하지만 그건 한 달에 한 번이면 돼요. 사람들은 발명(invention)은 엄청 많은 시간이 걸린다고 생각해요. 사실 한 번 좋은 아이디어가 생기면 그걸 실현하는 데 오히려 수년이 걸리는 경우가 많아요.
text_zh: 两个小时就够了，但一个月只需要这么两个小时。大家总以为搞发明创造要花很多时间。其实吧，一旦你有了一个好点子，真正把它做出来往往要好几年。
text_es: Dos horas está genial, pero solo necesitas esas dos horas una vez al mes. La gente piensa que inventar requiere un montón de tiempo. La cosa es que una vez que tienes una buena idea, muchas veces te toma años desarrollarla bien.
context: Lenny asks about practical advice for product managers who want to get better at invention and innovation. Ethan explains that becoming inventive requires dedicated thinking time, but emphasizes that the time commitment is much smaller than people believe - just two hours monthly of focused brainstorming. He explains that the real work comes after having the initial idea, in the years-long process of developing and implementing that concept into reality.
vocabulary_highlights: express that

speaker: Ethan Evans
speaker_expertise: Executive Coaching, Leadership Development, Product Strategy
text: And so I have this patent, and we haven't seen this become reality yet. I'm waiting for my idea to become part of Amazon's drone delivery system, but I think ultimately it will.
text_ko: 저는 이 특허(patent)를 가지고 있는데 아직 현실화되진 않았어요. 제 아이디어가 아마존의 드론 배송 시스템(drone delivery system)에 반영되길 기다리고 있고, 결국 그렇게 될 거라고 생각해요.
text_zh: 所以我有这个专利，但还没看到它真正实现。我在等着我的想法能用到亚马逊的无人机配送系统里，不过我觉得最终肯定会实现的。
text_es: Y entonces tengo esta patente, y todavía no hemos visto que esto se haga realidad. Estoy esperando a que mi idea se integre al sistema de entrega con drones de Amazon, pero creo que al final va a pasar.
context: Ethan shares his invention of a drone delivery system where drones operate from a moving truck instead of flying directly from warehouses. He describes how he combined two existing concepts - drone delivery and aircraft carriers - to create this patent. The quote shows his confidence that Amazon will eventually implement his innovation, demonstrating how inventors often wait years to see their ideas come to fruition.
vocabulary_highlights: become part of, ultimately

speaker: Ethan Evans
speaker_expertise: Executive Coaching, Leadership Development, Product Strategy
text: When you want to return something as opposed to taking it to the UPS Store or whatever, you just put it on your porch, and then on your phone, on your app, maybe you take a picture of it so that the drone can recognize the box or you put it in a designated spot, and you push a button and the drone takes your return away.
text_ko: 반품하러 UPS 매장 같은 데까지 갖고 갈 필요 없이 그냥 집 현관 앞에 놔두면 돼요. 그리고 휴대폰의 앱(app)에서 아마 박스를 드론(drone)이 인식하게 사진을 찍거나 지정된 자리에 놓고 버튼만 누르면 드론이 반품 물건을 가져가요.
text_zh: 你要退货的话，不用跑UPS Store什么的了，直接把东西放门口就行。然后在手机app上操作一下，可能拍个照让无人机识别包裹，或者放到指定位置，按个键，无人机就把你要退的东西拿走了。
text_es: Cuando quieres devolver algo, en lugar de llevarlo a la tienda de UPS o lo que sea, simplemente lo dejas en tu porche, y luego desde tu celular, en la app, tal vez le tomas una foto para que el dron pueda reconocer la caja o lo pones en un lugar específico, presionas un botón y el dron se lleva tu devolución.
context: Lenny expresses excitement about Ethan's drone delivery patent and suggests returns could also use the system. Ethan elaborates on how his truck-based drone delivery system would handle returns, describing the user experience where customers simply place items on their porch and use an app to request pickup. This demonstrates how good inventions can be extended beyond their original purpose to solve additional problems.
vocabulary_highlights: as opposed to, designated spot, takes your return away

speaker: Ethan Evans
speaker_expertise: Executive Coaching, Leadership Development, Product Strategy
text: But the other thing that causes people to get stuck is the difference between a senior manager and a director is how you lead and the work you're doing. And you can get as far as senior manager by being really strong in your function and being really good at getting things done. As a director, and as a VP beyond that, it becomes much more about influence, coordination with others, and letting go of being in all the details yourself.
text_ko: 사람들이 멈춰 서는 또 다른 이유는 시니어 매니저(senior manager)와 디렉터(director)의 차이가 어떻게 리드하느냐와 어떤 일을 하느냐에 있기 때문이에요. 자기 담당 분야에서 실력 있고 일을 잘 해내면 시니어 매니저까지는 올라갈 수 있어요. 하지만 디렉터, 그 위의 부사장(VP)급이 되면 훨씬 더 영향력 발휘와 다른 사람들과의 조율, 그리고 모든 세부사항을 직접 챙기려는 걸 내려놓는 일이 중요해져요.
text_zh: 但是另一个让人卡住的地方就是，高级经理和总监之间的区别在于你怎么带团队，还有你做的工作性质。你可以凭着在自己专业领域很强，执行力很棒，一路做到高级经理。但是到了总监这个级别，更别说VP了，就更多的是要靠影响力，跟其他部门协调配合，还要学会放手，不能什么细节都要自己抓。
text_es: Pero lo que también hace que la gente se quede estancada es que hay una diferencia enorme entre ser gerente senior y director en cuanto a cómo lideras y el tipo de trabajo que haces. Puedes llegar hasta gerente senior siendo muy fuerte en tu área y siendo excelente ejecutando cosas. Pero como director, y más aún como VP, se trata mucho más de influencia, de coordinarte con otros, y de soltar el control de todos los detalles.
context: Lenny asks about advice for senior managers who are stuck and unable to advance to director level. Ethan explains that beyond the structural challenges like fewer available roles, there's a fundamental shift in required skills. He describes how senior managers can succeed through functional expertise and execution, but director-level roles demand different capabilities focused on strategic thinking and working through others rather than direct hands-on work.
vocabulary_highlights: get stuck, strong in your function, getting things done, letting go of being in all the details

speaker: Ethan Evans
speaker_expertise: Executive Coaching, Leadership Development, Product Strategy
text: However, there is a lot you can do. A lot is in your control. And what is in your control is to start practicing those next level skills. Start working with your leadership on, where can I take on a strategic project? How can I become more of an inventor?
text_ko: 하지만 할 수 있는 일이 많아요. 많은 것이 본인 통제 안에 있어요. 통제할 수 있는 것 중 하나는 바로 그런 다음 단계 역량(next-level skills)을 연습하기 시작하는 거예요. 리더십(leadership)과 함께 어디서 전략적 프로젝트(strategic project)를 맡아볼 수 있을지 이야기해 보세요. 또 어떻게 하면 더 발명가(inventor)처럼 될 수 있을지도 고민해 보세요.
text_zh: 不过呢，你能做的事情其实挺多的。很多东西都在你的掌控范围内。你能控制的就是开始练习那些更高层次的技能。开始跟你的领导沟通，看看我能不能接手一些战略性的项目？怎么样才能让我更有创新精神，成为一个发明家？
text_es: Sin embargo, sí hay mucho que puedes hacer. Muchas cosas están en tus manos. Y lo que sí puedes controlar es empezar a practicar esas habilidades del siguiente nivel. Empieza a trabajar con tu liderazgo preguntando: ¿dónde puedo agarrar un proyecto estratégico? ¿Cómo puedo volverme más innovador?
context: Lenny asks if there's anything senior managers can do beyond waiting for promotion opportunities to open up. Ethan acknowledges that patience is required due to structural limitations, but emphasizes that aspiring directors can actively develop executive-level capabilities. He advises focusing on strategic work and invention - skills that distinguish directors from senior managers - rather than waiting passively for opportunities.
vocabulary_highlights: a lot is in your control, next level skills, take on, become more of an inventor

speaker: Ethan Evans
speaker_expertise: Executive Coaching, Leadership Development, Product Strategy
text: And so as a leader, I had to think, is what I'm doing going to generate a New York Times headline? Because if it is, I'd better be really careful. And that's what I taught myself is you can't be paralyzed, but I taught my whole team, we don't want to be in the New York Times for the wrong thing.
text_ko: 그래서 리더로서 저는 항상 "내가 하는 일이 뉴욕타임스(New York Times) 헤드라인이 될까?"라고 생각해야 했어요. 만약 그렇다면 정말 조심해야 해요. 그렇다고 해서 아무 것도 못 하고 마비돼서는 안 된다고 스스로 배웠고, 팀에게도 "우리는 잘못된 일로 뉴욕타임스에 나오고 싶지 않다"라고 계속 얘기했어요.
text_zh: 所以作为领导，我得想想，我现在做的事会不会上《纽约时报》的头条？如果会的话，那我得格外小心。我给自己的教训就是，你不能因为害怕就什么都不敢做，但我告诉我整个团队，咱们可不想因为负面新闻上《纽约时报》。
text_es: Y entonces como líder, tenía que preguntarme: ¿lo que estoy haciendo va a terminar siendo noticia en el New York Times? Porque si es así, mejor me ando con mucho cuidado. Y eso es lo que aprendí: no te puedes paralizar, pero le enseñé a todo mi equipo que no queremos salir en el New York Times por las razones equivocadas.
context: Lenny asks what Ethan learned from his major failure launching Amazon's App Store in front of Jeff Bezos. Ethan describes how he had to change his approach from being an 'operational cowboy' who prioritized speed over caution. He developed a mental framework of considering whether his decisions could generate negative media coverage, teaching his team to balance speed with appropriate risk assessment at Amazon's scale.
vocabulary_highlights: generate a New York Times headline, I'd better be really careful, can't be paralyzed, for the wrong thing

speaker: Ethan Smith
text: The first thing is just recognizing that this is related to search. So it's LLM plus RAG, it's summarizing a set of search results usually. So LLM plus RAG, number one. Number two is topics. So in search, a landing page is targeting hundreds of keywords, which we talked about on the last podcast.
text_ko: 먼저 이건 검색과 관련돼 있다는 걸 인지하는 게 중요해요. 보통 대형 언어 모델(LLM)과 RAG(Retrieval-Augmented Generation)이 결합돼서 검색 결과들을 요약하는 식이에요. 그래서 LLM과 RAG가 첫 번째이고요. 두 번째는 토픽(topics)이에요. 검색에서는 랜딩 페이지(landing page)가 수백 개의 키워드(keywords)를 한꺼번에 타깃팅한다는 점인데, 이건 지난 팟캐스트(podcast)에서 얘기했던 내용이에요.
text_zh: 首先得明白，这个其实就是跟搜索有关的。就是大语言模型(LLM)加上检索增强生成(RAG)，通常就是把一堆搜索结果给总结一下。所以第一点就是LLM加RAG。第二点是话题性。在搜索这块儿，一个落地页(landing page)要针对几百个关键词，这个我们在上期播客里聊过。
text_es: Lo primero es simplemente reconocer que esto está relacionado con las búsquedas. O sea, es LLM más RAG, básicamente está resumiendo un conjunto de resultados de búsqueda. Entonces, LLM más RAG, ese es el punto número uno. El número dos son los temas. En las búsquedas, una página de destino (landing page) está dirigida a cientos de palabras clave, que ya comentamos en el podcast anterior.
context: Lenny asks Ethan what are the most important things for people to understand to be successful in Answer Engine Optimization (AEO). Ethan explains that AEO works through LLM plus RAG (Retrieval-Augmented Generation), meaning the AI model searches for and then summarizes multiple sources rather than just using its training data. He emphasizes that like traditional SEO, each page should target broad topics with hundreds or thousands of related keywords and questions, not just single terms.
vocabulary_highlights: LLM plus RAG, set of search results, targeting hundreds of keywords
topics: Product Management, Growth & Marketing, Strategy & Planning

speaker: Ethan Smith
text: That's not the case for Answer Engine Optimization, because you can get mentioned by a citation tomorrow and start showing up immediately. You can have a Reddit thread, you can have a YouTube video. You can be mentioned on a blog, like a brand-new YC company launches, everyone's talking about them. They could show up in an answer tomorrow as a result of that. So early-stage companies can win, they can win quickly.
text_ko: 그건 답변 엔진 최적화(Answer Engine Optimization)의 경우는 달라요. 내일 누군가 언급(인용)해주기만 해도 바로 답변에 나타나기 시작할 수 있어요. 레딧 스레드가 올라가거나 유튜브 영상이 생기거나 블로그에 언급되는 것만으로도 가능해요. 예컨대 막 와이컴비네이터(YC) 신생 기업이 런칭해서 모두가 그 얘기를 하고 있다면, 그 영향으로 내일 당장 답변에 등장할 수 있어요. 그래서 초기 단계의 회사들은 승산이 있어요, 그것도 아주 빠르게요.
text_zh: 但答案引擎优化(Answer Engine Optimization)就不是这样了，你明天就可能被引用，然后马上就能出现在结果里。你可以有个Reddit帖子，可以有个YouTube视频，也可以在博客上被提到，比如一家刚成立的YC公司上线了，大家都在讨论他们，结果他们明天就可能出现在答案里。所以初创公司是有机会的，而且能赢得很快。
text_es: Pero con la Optimización para Motores de Respuesta (Answer Engine Optimization) es diferente, porque te pueden mencionar en una cita mañana y empezar a aparecer de inmediato. Puedes tener un hilo en Reddit, puedes tener un video de YouTube. Te pueden mencionar en un blog, como cuando se lanza una nueva empresa de YC y todo mundo está hablando de ellos. Pueden aparecer en una respuesta mañana como resultado de eso. Así que las empresas en etapa temprana sí pueden ganar, y pueden ganar rápido.
context: Lenny and Ethan are discussing how AEO differs from traditional SEO for startups. Ethan explains that traditional SEO requires significant domain authority that takes time to build, making it unsuitable for early-stage companies. However, with AEO, companies can appear in AI-generated answers immediately by getting mentioned in various online sources, without needing to build up domain authority first.
vocabulary_highlights: get mentioned by a citation, show up immediately, early-stage companies can win
topics: Starting a Company, Growth & Marketing, Strategy & Planning

speaker: Ethan Smith
text: They are significantly more valuable. So Webflow, we saw a 6X conversion rate difference between LLM traffic and Google Search traffic. Six times so significantly more qualified. I think that's probably for a couple of reasons. Probably it's because you're so primed because you're having a conversation with multiple follow-ups, and so there's so much intent that you've built.
text_ko: 그 트래픽이 훨씬 더 가치가 있었어요. 예를 들어 Webflow에서는 대형 언어 모델(LLM) 트래픽이 구글 검색(Google Search) 트래픽보다 전환율이 6배나 높게 나왔어요. 즉 훨씬 더 적합한(qualified) 트래픽이었던 거죠. 아마 그건 몇 가지 이유가 있는데, 특히 대화를 여러 차례 이어가며 후속 질문(follow-ups)이 쌓이기 때문에 사용자가 이미 충분히 프라이밍(prime)돼 있고 그만큼 의도(intent)가 많이 형성돼 있기 때문인 것 같아요.
text_zh: 这些流量的价值要高得多。就拿Webflow来说，我们发现LLM流量和谷歌搜索流量的转化率差了6倍。整整6倍，质量明显更高。我觉得可能有几个原因。主要是因为用户已经被充分"预热"了，他们跟AI有过多轮对话，来来回回问了很多问题，所以购买意向(intent)已经建立得很充分了。
text_es: Son significativamente más valiosos. O sea, en Webflow vimos una diferencia de 6 veces en la tasa de conversión entre el tráfico de LLM y el tráfico de búsqueda de Google. Seis veces más cualificado, ¿eh? Creo que esto se debe a un par de razones. Probablemente es porque ya vienes preparado porque estás teniendo una conversación con varias preguntas de seguimiento, entonces has construido muchísima intención de compra.
context: Lenny asks whether leads from answer engines like ChatGPT are actually valuable for B2B SaaS companies. Ethan shares data from their work with Webflow showing that visitors from AI platforms convert at six times the rate of Google Search traffic. He explains this higher conversion rate is likely due to the conversational nature of AI interactions, where users build intent through multiple follow-up questions before clicking through to a website.
vocabulary_highlights: significantly more qualified, you're so primed, so much intent that you've built

speaker: Ethan Smith
text: The obvious strategy for a growth person is, 'Let's make a bunch of automated spam and spam Reddit all over the place and get my product to show up everywhere.' That's the growth mindset, which makes sense, the hustle mindset. So what are people looking at? They're looking at creating hundreds of fake Reddit accounts pretending to be someone that you're not.
text_ko: 그로스 담당자(growth person)가 택하는 뻔한 전략은 "자동화된 대량 스팸(spam)을 만들어 레딧(Reddit) 여기저기 뿌려 우리 제품을 어디서든 보이게 하자" 하는 거예요. 그게 바로 성장 마인드셋(growth mindset)이죠 — 말이 되긴 해요, 허슬 마인드셋(hustle mindset)이니까요. 그래서 결국 사람들이 하는 건 수백 개의 가짜 레딧(Reddit) 계정을 만들어 본인이 아닌 다른 사람인 척 활동하는 거예요.
text_zh: 做增长的人最容易想到的套路就是，"咱们搞一堆自动化的垃圾信息，到处刷Reddit，让我的产品满天飞。" 这就是典型的增长思维(growth mindset)，也就是那种拼命折腾的心态(hustle mindset)，听起来挺有道理的。所以这些人在干嘛呢？他们在批量注册几百个假的Reddit账号，装成别人。
text_es: La estrategia obvia para alguien enfocado en crecimiento es: "Hagamos un montón de spam automatizado y llenemos Reddit por todos lados para que mi producto aparezca en todas partes." Esa es la mentalidad de crecimiento (growth mindset), que tiene sentido, la mentalidad del hustle. Entonces, ¿qué está haciendo la gente? Están creando cientos de cuentas falsas de Reddit, haciéndose pasar por alguien que no son.
context: Ethan is explaining why Reddit is heavily cited in AI responses and the temptation for companies to game the system. He describes the obvious but flawed strategy many growth marketers consider - creating fake Reddit accounts to spam promotional content. This approach fails because Reddit's community is good at detecting and removing spam, and authentic engagement is what actually works for getting cited in AI responses.
vocabulary_highlights: the growth mindset, the hustle mindset, spam Reddit all over the place

speaker: Ethan Smith
text: So the Reddit strategy is the obvious strategy, which is just to be an actual user of Reddit. Make an account, say who you are, say where you work, and give a useful answer. And that sounds simple if you're not in the growth mindset of, 'I need to scale this to hundreds of comments.' But you don't actually need 10,000 comments, even five could be great and that scales perfectly well.
text_ko: Reddit 전략은 사실 가장 당연한 전략이에요: 그냥 실제 Reddit 사용자처럼 행동하면 돼요. 계정 하나 만들고 누구인지, 어디서 일하는지 밝히고 유용한 답변을 해 주세요. '이걸 수백 개의 댓글로 키워야 해'라는 식의 성장 마인드셋(growth mindset)에 빠져 있지 않다면 아주 단순하게 느껴질 거예요. 사실 1만 개의 댓글이 필요한 건 아니고, 다섯 개만 있어도 훌륭할 수 있고 그 정도면 충분히 확장(scale)돼요.
text_zh: 所以Reddit的策略其实很简单明了，就是你真的去当个Reddit用户。注册个账号，说明你是谁，在哪工作，然后给出有用的回答。如果你不是抱着"我得把这个规模化到几百条评论"的增长思维，这听起来就很简单。但实际上你根本不需要发一万条评论，哪怕就五条也能很棒，而且这样的规模完全够用。
text_es: Entonces la estrategia de Reddit es la estrategia obvia, que es simplemente ser un usuario real de Reddit. Te haces una cuenta, dices quién eres, dices dónde trabajas, y das una respuesta útil. Y eso suena sencillo si no estás en la mentalidad de crecimiento (growth mindset) de "necesito escalar esto a cientos de comentarios." Pero la verdad es que no necesitas 10,000 comentarios, incluso cinco pueden ser geniales y eso escala perfectamente bien.
context: Ethan is contrasting the failed spam approach to Reddit with the successful strategy for getting mentioned in AI citations. Instead of trying to scale fake engagement, he recommends authentic participation where company representatives transparently identify themselves and provide genuinely helpful answers to Reddit discussions. This authentic approach works better than mass automation because quality matters more than quantity.
vocabulary_highlights: be an actual user, that scales perfectly well, growth mindset

speaker: Ethan Smith
text: Google's slice of the pie stays the same. The pie gets bigger. And so misinformation about Google going down, Google is not going down. Google published something recently, their VP of search explicitly said, 'I looked at the traffic that we're sending to publishers, and it is not down, it's up slightly.'
text_ko: 구글의 시장 점유율(share)은 그대로예요. 대신 전체 파이(pie)가 커지고 있는 거예요. 그래서 '구글이 망한다'는 식의 오해가 퍼지고 있는데, 그건 사실이 아니에요. 구글이 하락하고 있는 게 아니라는 거예요. 구글도 최근에 발표했고, 검색 담당 부사장(VP of Search)이 직접 "퍼블리셔(publishers)에 보내는 트래픽(traffic)을 봤는데 줄지 않았고, 오히려 약간 늘었다"고 말했어요.
text_zh: 谷歌的市场份额还是那样，没变。但整个市场盘子变大了。所以那些说谷歌要完蛋的消息都是瞎传，谷歌根本没有下滑。谷歌最近发了个声明，他们搜索业务的VP明确说过：'我看了我们给发布商导的流量，不但没降，还略微涨了一点。'
text_es: La porción del pastel que tiene Google sigue igual. Pero el pastel se hace más grande. Entonces toda esa desinformación de que Google está cayendo, Google no se está cayendo para nada. Google publicó algo hace poco, su vicepresidente de búsquedas dijo claramente: 'Revisé el tráfico que les estamos enviando a los editores, y no está bajando, de hecho está subiendo un poquito.'
context: Ethan is addressing common misinformation about AI and search, specifically the narrative that Google Search is dying due to AI-powered answer engines. He explains that new search surfaces like TikTok, Instagram, and now AI chatbots don't replace Google - they expand the total market for search and discovery. Google continues to send traffic to publishers, contradicting claims that AI overviews are killing traditional search traffic.
vocabulary_highlights: Google's slice of the pie stays the same, the pie gets bigger, misinformation

speaker: Evan LaPointe
speaker_expertise: Team Building, Product Strategy, User Experience
text: The brain is like a college campus that has different departments in it. Most people rely on their history department way too much. If you instead send things to the more experimental, open-minded science department, the more creative art department, you get dramatically better answers.
text_ko: 뇌는 여러 학과가 모여 있는 대학 캠퍼스 같아요. 대부분 사람들은 역사학과(history department)에만 지나치게 의존해요. 대신 좀 더 실험적이고 열린 마음의 과학학과(science department), 더 창의적인 예술학과(art department)에 물어보면 훨씬 더 나은 답을 얻을 수 있어요.
text_zh: 大脑就像个大学校园，里面有各个不同的院系。大多数人太依赖历史系了，老是翻旧账。如果你把问题交给更爱试验、更开放的理科院系，或者更有创意的艺术系去处理，你会得到好得多的答案。
text_es: El cerebro es como un campus universitario con diferentes facultades. La mayoría de la gente depende demasiado de su facultad de historia. Pero si en cambio mandas las cosas a la facultad de ciencias, que es más experimental y de mente abierta, o a la facultad de arte, que es más creativa, obtienes respuestas muchísimo mejores.
context: Lenny asks Evan to explain how the brain works in simple terms that people can understand and apply to their work. Evan introduces his framework for understanding the brain as having different "departments" like a college campus - a science department for experimentation, an art department for creativity, and a history department for looking up existing knowledge. He explains that most people default to their history department because it's the lowest energy way for the brain to generate answers, but this limits innovation and problem-solving potential.
vocabulary_highlights: experimental, open-minded, dramatically better answers

speaker: Evan LaPointe
speaker_expertise: Team Building, Product Strategy, User Experience
text: It's almost like you're playing Elden Ring or some video game. The starting point is to choose your character. Hey, I'm the devil's advocate approach, or I'm the break it and see if it still stands after I hit it really hard with a sledgehammer kind of guy, your personality kind of has a natural fit.
text_ko: 거의 엘든 링(Elden Ring) 같은 비디오게임을 하는 느낌이에요. 시작점은 캐릭터를 고르는 거고요. '저는 악마의 옹호자(devil's advocate) 스타일이에요'라든가 '망치로 세게 내려쳐도 버티는지 부숴보고 확인하는 타입이에요' 같은 성격이 자연스럽게 맞아요.
text_zh: 这就像你在玩《艾尔登法环》或者别的电子游戏一样。首先得选角色对吧。比如说，嘿，我就是那种专门唱反调的人，或者我就是那种喜欢把东西砸烂了看看还能不能用的人——你的性格总会找到适合的定位。
text_es: Es como si estuvieras jugando Elden Ring o algún videojuego. El punto de partida es elegir tu personaje. Oye, yo soy del tipo "abogado del diablo" o soy más bien del estilo "lo rompo a ver si aguanta después de darle con todo", tu personalidad como que tiene un encaje natural.
context: Lenny asks about Evan's advice on becoming more influential. Evan explains that the first step in influence is choosing your character or approach style, similar to selecting a character in a video game. He suggests that people should be intentional about their influence style rather than defaulting to whatever feels natural, and gives examples like being the "devil's advocate" or the person who stress-tests ideas by challenging them hard.
vocabulary_highlights: devil's advocate approach, hit it really hard with a sledgehammer, natural fit

speaker: Evan LaPointe
speaker_expertise: Team Building, Product Strategy, User Experience
text: It's critical to ask what kind of experience am I? Not how good am I at my job, how much do I know, how critical am I to this process, but am I a miserable experience? If the answer is yes, don't worry too much about the other pieces yet. You got to fix that first.
text_ko: 가장 중요한 건 '내가 어떤 경험(experience)을 주고 있나요?'라고 스스로 물어보는 거예요. 얼마나 일을 잘하느냐, 얼마나 아는 게 많느냐, 이 프로세스에서 내가 얼마나 중요한 사람이냐를 묻는 게 아니라, 내가 상대에게 끔찍한 경험을 주고 있는 건 아닌가를 먼저 보세요. 만약 그렇다면 다른 것들은 일단 너무 신경 쓰지 마세요. 그걸 먼저 고쳐야 해요.
text_zh: 关键是要问自己：我给别人的体验怎么样？不是问我工作能力强不强，懂得多不多，在这个流程里有多重要，而是问我是不是让人感觉很糟糕？如果答案是肯定的，那别的先别管了，得先把这个问题解决了。
text_es: Es fundamental preguntarse ¿qué tipo de experiencia soy yo? No qué tan bueno soy en mi trabajo, cuánto sé, o qué tan indispensable soy para este proceso, sino ¿soy una experiencia horrible? Si la respuesta es sí, no te preocupes tanto por las otras cosas todavía. Eso es lo primero que tienes que arreglar.
context: Lenny asks about creating better relationships within teams. Evan explains his framework for relationships which includes three components: ability, trust, and appeal (what kind of experience you are to others). He emphasizes that "appeal" - how people experience working with you - is actually the most important factor biologically, even more than your competence. If people find you miserable to work with, they'll avoid including you regardless of your skills.
vocabulary_highlights: miserable experience, critical to this process, fix that first

speaker: Evan LaPointe
speaker_expertise: Team Building, Product Strategy, User Experience
text: We spend gazillions of dollars on waste of time and meetings. For us, like in our programs, the average delta is between 10 and 20%. People save anywhere from a full half of a day to a full day per week of work as a result of just cleaning up the way they're using meetings.
text_ko: 우리는 시간 낭비와 불필요한 회의에 어마어마한 돈을 쓰고 있어요. 저희 프로그램의 경우 평균 변화폭(average delta)은 10~20% 정도예요. 사람들은 회의 활용 방식을 조금만 정리해도 주당 반나절에서 하루까지 업무 시간을 절약해요.
text_zh: 我们在无效会议上烧钱烧得厉害。拿我们的项目来说，平均改善幅度(delta)能达到10%到20%。光是把开会的方式理顺了，大家每周就能省出半天到一整天的工作时间。
text_es: Gastamos cantidades enormes de dinero en reuniones que son pura pérdida de tiempo. En nuestros programas, el cambio promedio está entre el 10 y 20%. La gente ahorra desde medio día completo hasta un día entero por semana de trabajo, simplemente por limpiar la forma en que manejan las reuniones.
context: Lenny asks for practical things people can do to work better with colleagues based on brain science. Evan discusses how poorly designed meetings waste enormous amounts of money and time in businesses. He shares that his programs typically help people save 10-20% of their time, or half a day to a full day per week, simply by improving how they structure and run meetings using neuroscience principles.
vocabulary_highlights: gazillions of dollars, average delta, cleaning up the way

speaker: Evan LaPointe
speaker_expertise: Team Building, Product Strategy, User Experience
text: Most meetings skip the priming step altogether. They launched directly into decision making. It would be safe to skip the priming step if we began the meeting under the assumption that everybody here is on the same page, has the same information, and generally speaking, intends for the same outcome.
text_ko: 대부분의 회의는 프라이밍 단계(priming step)를 아예 건너뛰어요. 바로 의사결정(decision making)으로 들어가 버리죠. 회의를 시작할 때 여기 있는 모두가 같은 생각을 하고 같은 정보를 공유하며 대체로 같은 결과를 원한다고 가정한다면 그 단계를 생략해도 괜찮아요.
text_zh: 大部分会议都直接跳过了铺垫环节，上来就开始做决策。如果我们开会时能确保大家想法一致，信息同步，目标也基本一样，那跳过铺垫倒也没什么问题。
text_es: La mayoría de las reuniones se saltan completamente el paso de preparación previa. Se lanzan directo a tomar decisiones. Sería seguro saltarse ese paso de preparación si empezáramos la reunión asumiendo que todos aquí estamos en la misma página, tenemos la misma información y, hablando en general, buscamos el mismo resultado.
context: Lenny asks for tactical advice people can implement this week to be more successful at work. Evan explains that most meetings fail because they skip "priming" - the step where you align everyone on context, information, and intended outcomes before making decisions. He points out that assuming everyone is on the same page is usually a false assumption, especially for teams that have been working together for more than a day.
vocabulary_highlights: skip the priming step, launched directly into, on the same page

speaker: Evan LaPointe
speaker_expertise: Team Building, Product Strategy, User Experience
text: Your ability is actually not the most important part of a relationship, biologically speaking. There's two more that matter quite a bit more. And the surprise ending is that the third one matters the most, which is scary in some cases.
text_ko: 사실 생물학적으로 보면, 관계에서 가장 중요한 건 당신의 능력이 아니에요. 능력 말고도 훨씬 더 중요한 요소가 두 가지 더 있는데요. 놀랍게도 그중 세 번째가 제일 중요해서, 경우에 따라선 오히려 무서울 수도 있어요.
text_zh: 从生物学角度来说，你的能力其实在人际关系中不是最重要的。还有两个因素要重要得多。最让人意外的是，第三个因素才是最关键的，这在某些情况下还挺可怕的。
text_es: En realidad, tu habilidad no es lo más importante en una relación, hablando desde el punto de vista biológico. Hay otras dos cosas que importan muchísimo más. Y lo que te va a sorprender es que la tercera es la que más cuenta, lo cual puede dar un poco de miedo en algunos casos.
context: Lenny asks about building better relationships within teams. Evan explains his three-component framework for understanding professional relationships: ability (your competence and skills), trust (perceived risk of working with you), and appeal (the experience of interacting with you). He reveals that while most people focus on demonstrating their ability, it's actually the least important factor biologically - trust and especially appeal matter much more for relationship quality.
vocabulary_highlights: biologically speaking, surprise ending, scary in some cases

speaker: Katie Dill
text: And so I came in swinging ready to go, and then about a month into my time there, I got a meeting on my calendar. Thursday 8:30 AM, was an hour and a half with half of the design team, so that was five people, and our HR partner. And so it was an extremely valuable learning experience and I took from that to then immediately shift how I was operating.
text_ko: 들어왔을 때는 바로 시작할 준비가 다 돼 있었어요. 그런데 거기서 한 달쯤 지났을 때 제 캘린더(calendar)에 회의가 잡혔어요. 목요일 오전 8시 30분에 1시간 반짜리였고 디자인팀(design team) 인원 절반인 다섯 명과 인사 파트너(HR partner)가 참석했어요. 정말 값진 배움이었고, 그걸 계기로 바로 제 업무 방식(일하는 방식)을 바꿨어요.
text_zh: 所以我一进去就干劲十足，准备大干一场。结果大概一个月后，我日程上突然多了个会议。周四早上8点半，要开一个半小时，参加的有设计团队一半的人，就是5个人，还有我们的HR合作伙伴。那次会议对我来说真的是个非常宝贵的学习机会，会后我马上就调整了自己的工作方式。
text_es: Entonces llegué con toda la actitud, listo para comermelo todo, y como al mes de estar ahí, me aparece una reunión en el calendario. Jueves 8:30 AM, hora y media con la mitad del equipo de diseño, o sea cinco personas, y nuestra compañera de Recursos Humanos. Y fue una experiencia súper valiosa de aprendizaje, así que de ahí mismo cambié completamente mi forma de operar.
context: Lenny asks Katie about a significant failure in her leadership career. Katie describes her first month as head of design at Airbnb, where she tried to make rapid changes to improve the team's low engagement scores and collaboration issues. However, five team members scheduled a formal meeting with HR to read from papers listing everything they thought she was doing wrong as a leader.
vocabulary_highlights: came in swinging, shift how I was operating

speaker: Katie Dill
text: And regardless of each individual thing, what was very clear was that the missing piece, the theme that was across all of that is that I hadn't earned their trust. So whether how right or how wrong what I was doing was is the key piece is that I wasn't bringing the team along with me.
text_ko: 그리고 각 사안을 떠나서 분명한 건, 모든 상황에 걸쳐 공통적으로 빠져 있던 부분은 제가 그들의 신뢰를 얻지 못했다는 거였어요. 제가 옳았든 틀렸든 핵심은 팀을 함께 데려가고 있지 못했다는 점이에요.
text_zh: 不管具体是什么事儿，有一点特别明显，就是我缺了最关键的一环——我没有赢得他们的信任。所以不管我做的事情对不对，核心问题是我没有把团队带起来，大家没有跟我一条心。
text_es: Y más allá de cada cosa en particular, lo que quedó clarísimo es que me faltaba una pieza clave, el hilo conductor de todo eso: no me había ganado su confianza. O sea, que tan acertado o equivocado que estuviera en lo que hacía, el punto clave es que no estaba llevando al equipo conmigo en el proceso.
context: Katie explains her realization after receiving harsh feedback from her design team at Airbnb. The team had formally complained about her leadership approach through HR after just one month. Katie reflects on what she learned from this difficult experience about the importance of building trust as a foundation for effective leadership.
vocabulary_highlights: bringing the team along with me

speaker: Paul Adams
speaker_expertise: AI/ML Products, User Experience, Product Design
text: I had some version of a panic attack, walked off stage, I was still mic'd up, cursed. I was laughing. I was like, 'Geez, are they laughing at me. Oh my God, this is...' But I can manage to turn it around, I walked back out, I'd kind of been disarmed internally in my head, and the rest of it went well.
text_ko: 공황발작(panic attack) 비슷한 게 왔어요. 무대에서 내려왔는데도 마이크가 붙어 있는 상태였고, 욕도 했어요. 웃어버렸고요. 속으로는 '사람들이 나 보고 웃는 건가? 세상에, 이게…'라고 생각했어요. 그런데 다행히 상황을 반전시킬 수 있었어요. 다시 무대로 나갔고, 머릿속의 긴장이 좀 풀린 기분이었고 나머지는 잘 진행됐어요.
text_zh: 我当时差点惊慌失措，直接走下台了，麦克风还开着呢，嘴里骂骂咧咧的。我还在那儿傻笑，心想"天哪，他们是在笑话我吗？我的天，这下完了..."不过我还是设法挽回了局面，重新走回台上，心里的那种紧张感反而消失了，后面就顺利多了。
text_es: Tuve algo así como un ataque de pánico, me bajé del escenario, todavía tenía el micrófono puesto, dije groserías. Me estaba riendo. Pensé, 'Dios mío, ¿se estarán burlando de mí? Ay no, esto está...' Pero logré darle la vuelta a la situación, regresé al escenario, como que ya me había relajado mentalmente, y el resto salió bien.
context: Lenny asks Paul about a memorable failure that scarred him for life. Paul describes freezing during a keynote speech at the world's biggest advertising festival in Cannes, representing Facebook. He had to walk off stage in front of thousands of people, and because his microphone was still on, the audience heard him curse. Despite this nightmare scenario, he managed to return and successfully complete his presentation.
vocabulary_highlights: mic'd up, disarmed internally, turn it around

speaker: Paul Adams
speaker_expertise: AI/ML Products, User Experience, Product Design
text: I think a lot of the motivation for those projects came from a place of fear. It didn't come from a place of let's make a great product for people, let's really understand the things people struggle with when communicating with family and friends. That's really, really try and create something wonderful. It came from a place of fear.
text_ko: 제 생각에는 그 프로젝트들에 대한 많은 동기가 두려움에서 온 것 같아요. 사람들을 위해 좋은 제품을 만들자거나, 사람들이 가족·친구와 소통하면서 겪는 어려움을 진짜로 이해해보자 하는 자리에서 나온 건 아니었어요. 진짜 멋진 걸 만들려고 정말 노력한 게 아니라, 결국 두려움에서 나온 거예요.
text_zh: 我觉得那些项目的动机很大程度上都是出于恐惧。不是说我们要为用户做个好产品，真正去理解大家在跟家人朋友沟通时遇到的痛点，然后真心实意地去创造一些很棒的东西。而是出于恐惧心理。
text_es: Creo que gran parte de la motivación detrás de esos proyectos venía del miedo. No venía de un lugar de "vamos a crear un producto increíble para la gente, vamos a entender de verdad con qué batallas la gente cuando se comunica con familia y amigos". De verdad intentar crear algo maravilloso. Venía del miedo.
context: Lenny asks Paul about his time working on failed social projects at Google like Google Buzz and Google+. Paul reflects on why these products failed, explaining that the motivation behind building them was fundamentally flawed. Instead of focusing on solving real user problems, the projects were driven by competitive fear of Facebook's success in social networking.
vocabulary_highlights: came from a place of fear

speaker: Tom Conrad
text: The critique that is often leveled at Pets.com or at least at the time, was like, this is just a stupid business. They're shipping dog food around. You could never make that work, and that's just wrong. You absolutely can make it work. Probably can't make it work when 80% of the country on the internet is still on dial up. It's really, really early.
text_ko: 당시 사람들은 Pets.com에 대해 “그건 그냥 말도 안 되는 사업이야. 강아지 사료나 배송하고는 절대 안 될 거야”라고들 비판했어요. 그런데 그건 틀렸어요. 충분히 성공시킬 수 있어요. 다만 그때는 인터넷 이용자의 80%가 아직 다이얼업(dial-up)이었으니 아마 그때는 성공시키기 어려웠을 거예요. 정말, 정말 초기 단계였어요.
text_zh: 当时大家对Pets.com最常见的批评就是，这生意太蠢了，就是在网上卖狗粮嘛，怎么可能赚钱，但这种想法是错的。这种模式绝对能成功。只不过在那个年代可能确实做不起来，因为全国80%的人上网还在用拨号连接(dial up)，时机确实太早了。
text_es: La crítica que siempre le echaban a Pets.com en esa época era como que "este negocio es una estupidez, están mandando comida para perros por ahí, eso jamás va a funcionar", y eso está completamente equivocado. Sí se puede hacer que funcione, absolutamente. Lo que pasa es que probablemente no puedes hacerlo funcionar cuando el 80% del país todavía se conecta a internet con dial-up. Era demasiado temprano, la verdad.
context: Lenny discusses how Tom took Pets.com from nothing to a public company to completely out of business in 19 months. Tom defends the business model, noting that Chewy later proved online pet retail could work with a $9 billion valuation. Tom explains that timing was crucial - Pets.com launched when internet adoption was still very limited, making the logistics and customer acquisition much more challenging than it would be later.
vocabulary_highlights: critique that is often leveled at

speaker: Sri Batchu
text: For me, failure is not that you didn't drive revenue, failure is not learning. So it's really important that you learn when you fail. And so we celebrate failure as long as you're learning, and you can only learn if you've designed the right test and you failed conclusively, because otherwise I think many of us have been in situations where there's intuition that something might work and it doesn't work, and then you end up doing it over and over for years.
text_ko: 제게 실패는 매출(revenue)을 못 올린 게 아니라 배우지 못한 거예요. 그래서 실패했을 때 배우는 게 정말 중요해요. 배우고 있다면 실패를 오히려 축하해요. 다만 제대로 된 테스트(test)를 설계해서 명확하게 실패했을 때에만 진짜 배울 수 있어요. 그렇지 않으면 많은 분들이 ‘이게 통할 것 같다’는 직관(intuition)은 있는데 실제로는 안 되는데도 수년 동안 같은 걸 계속 반복하게 돼요.
text_zh: 对我来说，失败不是指你没做出业绩，真正的失败是你没有从中学到东西。所以失败了以后一定要有收获，这特别重要。只要你能从中学到东西，我们就鼓励试错，但前提是你得设计好测试方案，让失败来得明明白白，要不然很多时候我们凭感觉觉得某个方法可能行，结果不行，然后就一直重复同样的错误，搞好几年都没进展。
text_es: Para mí, el fracaso no es que no hayas generado ingresos, el fracaso es no aprender. Entonces es súper importante que aprendas cuando fallas. Por eso celebramos el fracaso siempre y cuando estés aprendiendo, y solo puedes aprender si diseñaste bien la prueba y fallaste de manera concluyente, porque si no, creo que muchos de nosotros hemos estado en situaciones donde hay una corazonada de que algo podría funcionar y no funciona, y entonces terminas haciéndolo una y otra vez durante años.
context: Lenny asks Sri about creating a culture where people aren't afraid to take risks, given that growth experiments typically have only a 30% success rate. Sri explains his philosophy that the real failure isn't when experiments don't drive revenue - it's when teams don't learn from their failed attempts. He emphasizes the importance of designing conclusive tests to avoid repeatedly trying the same ineffective approaches.
vocabulary_highlights: failed conclusively

speaker: Jiaona Zhang (JZ)
text: I think there wasn't really a clear path. I think there was [inaudible]. Exactly. And it was more just like if you understood, again, this is my point around unit economics, there are things where I think you have magical thinking around unit economics. You're like, 'Well, when we get to the scale of X, it's all going to work out. We can make these things happen.' I think you actually need to really make sure the unit economics work right at the beginning.
text_ko: 솔직히 말하면 뚜렷한 길이 있던 건 아닌 것 같아요. 중간에 잘 안 들리는 부분도 있었고요. 맞아요. 제 요점은 유닛 이코노믹스(unit economics)에 관한 건데, 어떤 부분에서는 이걸 마치 마법처럼 생각하는 경향이 있어요. ‘우리가 어느 정도 규모(X)에 도달하면 다 해결될 거야, 이렇게 만들 수 있을 거야’라고요. 근데 저는 실제로 초반부터 유닛 이코노믹스가 제대로 맞는지 확실히 해야 한다고 생각해요.
text_zh: 我觉得当时确实没有一个很清晰的路径。对，就是这样。更多的是如果你理解了——这又回到我说的单位经济效益(unit economics)的问题，有些时候你对单位经济效益会有一种不切实际的想法。你会想："等我们达到X这个规模的时候，一切都会顺理成章，我们就能把这些事情搞定了。" 但我觉得你其实需要从一开始就确保单位经济效益是行得通的。
text_es: Creo que no había realmente un camino claro. Creo que había [inaudible]. Exacto. Y era más bien como si entendieras, otra vez, este es mi punto sobre la economía unitaria (unit economics), hay cosas donde creo que tienes un pensamiento mágico alrededor de la economía unitaria. Te dices, 'Bueno, cuando lleguemos a la escala de X, todo va a funcionar. Podemos hacer que estas cosas pasen.' Creo que realmente necesitas asegurarte de que la economía unitaria funcione desde el mero principio.
context: Lenny asks JZ whether Airbnb Plus could have succeeded with better execution or if the business model was fundamentally flawed. Airbnb Plus was an attempt to create managed, inspected inventory to address trust issues, but it required significant operational investment. JZ explains that the project suffered from 'magical thinking' about unit economics - the belief that profitability would somehow emerge at scale without the fundamental economics working from the start.
vocabulary_highlights: magical thinking around unit economics

speaker: Gina Gotthilf
speaker_expertise: Growth Strategy, Marketing Strategy, Community Building
text: But between all of those highlights, there were so many B moments that get shoved under the rug because it's just easier for me and it's more impressive for others. But I really like to highlight those because I think that most of us have a lot of B moments every day, every week, every month, and every period of our lives.
text_ko: 하지만 그런 하이라이트들 사이사이에, 저한테는 더 편하고 다른 사람들에게는 더 인상적이니까 그냥 숨겨 버려지는 B 순간들(B moments)이 정말 많아요. 저는 오히려 그런 순간들을 더 부각시키는 걸 좋아해요. 대부분의 사람들이 매일, 매주, 매달, 그리고 인생의 여러 시기마다 이런 B 순간들을 많이 겪는다고 생각하거든요.
text_zh: 但是在这些高光时刻之间，其实有很多平平无奇的B级时刻，我们往往会把这些藏起来不说，因为对我来说这样更省事，对别人来说也显得我更厉害。但我特别想说说这些平凡时刻，因为我觉得咱们大部分人每天、每周、每月，人生的每个阶段，其实都有很多这样的B级时刻。
text_es: Pero entre todos esos momentos destacados, hubo muchísimos momentos B que uno tiende a barrer bajo la alfombra porque es más fácil para mí y queda mejor ante los demás. Pero me gusta mucho resaltar esos momentos porque creo que la mayoría de nosotros tenemos un montón de momentos B todos los días, todas las semanas, todos los meses, y en cada etapa de nuestras vidas.
context: Lenny asks Gina about her concept of having both an 'A side' and 'B side' to everyone's career - where the A side contains impressive achievements that people share publicly. Gina explains that people naturally focus on sharing their highlights (A side) while hiding their failures and struggles (B side), but she believes it's important to acknowledge these B moments because they're a normal part of everyone's professional journey.
vocabulary_highlights: get shoved under the rug

speaker: Fareed Mosavat
speaker_expertise: Product Management, Growth Strategy, Data Analytics
text: You can't do homework. You can't do exercises. You can't do fake stuff. You have to work on real products at real companies with real customers, with real data to get better at product management. So any kind of training, mentorship, reading, et cetera that you do is just a layer on top of that.
text_ko: 숙제나 연습, 모의 작업으론 안 돼요. 프로덕트 매니지먼트(product management)를 잘하려면 실제 제품을, 실제 회사에서, 실제 고객을 대상으로, 실제 데이터를 가지고 직접 일해봐야 해요. 그러니까 어떤 교육이나 멘토링, 독서 등은 그 위에 얹어지는 보조적인 것일 뿐이에요.
text_zh: 你没法通过做作业、做练习题或者搞一些虚的东西来提升产品管理能力。你必须在真实的公司里，面对真实的客户，用真实的数据来做真实的产品，这样才能真正提高。所以什么培训啊、导师指导啊、看书学习啊这些，都只是锦上添花而已。
text_es: No puedes hacer tareas teóricas. No puedes hacer ejercicios de práctica. No puedes trabajar con cosas inventadas. Tienes que trabajar en productos reales, en empresas reales, con clientes reales, con datos reales para mejorar en gestión de productos. Entonces cualquier tipo de capacitación, mentoría, lectura, etcétera que hagas es solo una capa adicional encima de eso.
context: Lenny asks Fareed why it's so hard to become better as a product manager and why it's innately tricky to develop PM skills. Fareed explains that product management requires what Naval Ravikant calls 'specific knowledge' - knowledge that can only be gained through actual experience doing the work. Unlike engineering where you can get foundational knowledge through bootcamps or computer science education, PM skills can't be learned through theoretical training alone.
vocabulary_highlights: fake stuff, a layer on top of that

speaker: Fareed Mosavat
speaker_expertise: Product Management, Growth Strategy, Data Analytics
text: At the foundation of it is when I first got there, I thought what was important was modeling how things work in the real world. They're making things look right, so to speak. What I learned there is that actually, you're trying to deliver an end experience, and product, and story to your viewers, to your audience.
text_ko: 처음 거기에 갔을 때는 현실에서 사물이 어떻게 작동하는지를 모델링(modeling)하는 게 중요하다고 생각했어요. 다시 말하면 보기만 그럴듯하게 만드는 거였죠. 그런데 거기서 배운 건 사실 우리가 하려는 건 시청자나 관객에게 최종 경험(end experience), 제품(product), 그리고 이야기를 전달하는 거라는 점이었어요.
text_zh: 最根本的是，我刚到那里的时候，觉得重要的是要模拟现实世界的运作方式，就是让东西看起来对，你懂的。但我在那里学到的是，其实你要做的是给观众、给你的受众交付一个完整的体验、产品和故事。
text_es: Al final del día, cuando llegué ahí pensaba que lo importante era modelar cómo funcionan las cosas en el mundo real. O sea, hacer que las cosas se vean bien, por decirlo así. Lo que aprendí ahí es que en realidad, lo que buscas es entregar una experiencia completa, un producto y una historia a tus usuarios, a tu audiencia.
context: Lenny asks Fareed what he learned from his time at Pixar Animation Studios that has informed how he builds products or thinks about his career. Fareed worked at Pixar for almost seven years on visual effects, software tools, and creative technology for films like Finding Nemo, Cars, Wall-E, and Up. He explains how this experience taught him to focus on the end user experience rather than technical perfection.
vocabulary_highlights: so to speak, end experience

speaker: Fareed Mosavat
speaker_expertise: Product Management, Growth Strategy, Data Analytics
text: I think the hard part of this is I have not figured out how to do this well in a remote environment without throwing a lot of one-on-ones on people's calendars because sometimes you figured this out just by hearing conversations, hang out at lunch, and asking questions, and those kinds of things, but it's certainly not impossible.
text_ko: 어려운 건, 원격 근무 환경(remote environment)에서는 사람들 캘린더에 일대일 미팅(one-on-ones)을 잔뜩 잡아 넣지 않고는 이걸 잘 해내기가 쉽지 않다는 거예요. 가끔은 옆에서 대화 듣거나 점심 같이 어울리면서 질문하다가 해결되기도 하는데, 그런 기회가 원격에선 잘 안 생기거든요. 그래도 전혀 불가능한 건 아니에요.
text_zh: 我觉得难点在于，在远程办公的环境下，我还没想出怎么能做好这件事，又不用在大家日程里塞一堆一对一会议，因为有时候你就是通过听别人聊天、一起吃午饭、随便问问问题这些方式就能搞明白，但这肯定不是不可能的事。
text_es: Creo que lo complicado de esto es que no he logrado hacerlo bien en un entorno remoto sin llenar el calendario de la gente con reuniones uno a uno, porque a veces te enterabas de estas cosas simplemente escuchando conversaciones, charlando en el almuerzo, haciendo preguntas y ese tipo de cosas, pero desde luego no es imposible.
context: Fareed is discussing his framework for building curiosity and understanding across different levels of an organization - going 'two stack levels up, two stack levels down' to understand your manager's and their manager's priorities, as well as technical details below you. Lenny notes this advice doesn't necessarily require a lot more work, just research and thinking. Fareed acknowledges the challenge of doing this type of organizational learning in remote work environments.
vocabulary_highlights: throwing a lot of one-on-ones, hang out at lunch

speaker: Fareed Mosavat
speaker_expertise: Product Management, Growth Strategy, Data Analytics
text: I think there's a framework thing, and then there's like, 'What practical advice?' So from a framework perspective, I think it's important to ask the question, 'For each of the things that I am responsible for, what category does this fall into? What's important about it? What are the right ways to think about building that, given that it is different than what I've built before?'
text_ko: 제 생각에는 프레임워크(framework)적인 얘기가 있고, 또 '실무적으로 어떤 조언을 해주냐'는 얘기가 따로 있는 것 같아요. 프레임워크 관점에서는 제가 맡은 각각의 일이 어떤 카테고리(category)에 속하는지, 그 일에서 무엇이 중요한지, 그리고 이전에 만들던 것들과 다르다면 그걸 어떻게 접근해서 만들어야 하는지를 묻는 게 중요하다고 생각해요.
text_zh: 我觉得这里面有个框架性的东西，然后就是"有什么实用的建议？"从框架的角度来说，我觉得很重要的一点是要问自己："我负责的每一件事，它属于哪个类别？它的重点是什么？考虑到这跟我之前做过的不一样，应该用什么样的思路去搭建？"
text_es: Mira, creo que hay dos niveles: el tema del marco conceptual y luego el "¿qué hago en la práctica?" Desde el punto de vista del framework, me parece clave preguntarse: "De todas las cosas de las que soy responsable, ¿en qué categoría entra cada una? ¿Qué es lo importante aquí? ¿Cuáles son las mejores formas de enfocar la construcción de esto, considerando que es distinto a lo que he construido antes?"
context: Lenny asks for practical advice about learning new types of product work as you move from IC to manager roles. Fareed has just explained his framework of four types of product work: feature work, growth work, product-market fit expansion, and scaling work. He's explaining how moving up in product leadership requires understanding all these categories, not just being expert in one area like growth or features.
vocabulary_highlights: framework thing, what category does this fall into

speaker: Fareed Mosavat
speaker_expertise: Product Management, Growth Strategy, Data Analytics
text: When you're a leader, it's now your job to propose, 'What are the resources we need to have the most impact on this problem?' I think I personally have messed this up a bunch of times where at the end of the core, I'll be like, 'Yeah, but we only had four engineers, and this is what we could do.'
text_ko: 리더(leader)라면 이제 "'이 문제에 가장 큰 임팩트를 내려면 어떤 리소스(resources)가 필요할까?'라고 제안해야 해요." 저도 개인적으로 이걸 몇 번 망친 적이 있어요 — 핵심 단계(core)가 끝날 무렵이면 "우린 엔지니어(engineers)가 넷밖에 없었으니까 이게 우리가 할 수 있는 전부였어"라고 말하곤 했어요.
text_zh: 当你成为领导者的时候，你的职责就是要主动提出："我们需要什么资源才能最大程度地解决这个问题？" 我觉得我个人在这方面搞砸过很多次，经常到最后总结的时候会说："是啊，但我们只有四个工程师，能做的就这些了。"
text_es: Cuando eres líder, ahora tu trabajo es plantear: '¿Qué recursos necesitamos para tener el mayor impacto en este problema?' Creo que yo personalmente la he regado un montón de veces donde al final del día termino diciendo: 'Sí, pero solo teníamos cuatro ingenieros, y esto es lo que pudimos hacer.'
context: Fareed is explaining the second major mistake new product managers make when transitioning from IC to manager roles, which is part of what he calls the 'Product Leader Canyon.' He's describing how ICs typically focus on maximizing value with given resources, but leaders need to identify what resources are actually needed to solve problems effectively and make the case for those resources.
vocabulary_highlights: messed this up a bunch of times, at the end of the core

speaker: Fareed Mosavat
speaker_expertise: Product Management, Growth Strategy, Data Analytics
text: You need to have some breadth, right, but it's like same problem, different industry. It's one way to think about depth that's focused. Different problem, same industry is another way to think about it, but you have to come up with a unique intersection that is clearly you are in the top tier of the people who know how to do that.
text_ko: 어느 정도 폭넓이(breadth)는 필요하지만, 결국 본질은 같아요 — 같은 문제인데 업계만 다른 경우(same problem, different industry)는 초점을 둔 깊이(depth)를 생각하는 한 방식이에요. 반대로 문제는 다른데 같은 업계인 경우(different problem, same industry)는 또 다른 방식이고요. 하지만 결국에는 당신만의 고유한 교차점(unique intersection)을 만들어서, 그걸 해낼 줄 아는 사람들 중에서 분명히 최상위권(top tier)에 있다는 걸 보여줄 수 있어야 해요.
text_zh: 你得有一定的广度，对吧，但其实是同样的问题，只是换了个行业。这是一种专注深度的思路。换个问题，但还是同一个行业，这又是另一种思路，但关键是你得找到一个独特的交集点，让你明显处在那个领域最顶尖的那批人当中。
text_es: Necesitas tener cierta amplitud, ¿no?, pero es como el mismo problema en distinta industria. Es una forma de pensar en profundidad pero enfocada. Problema diferente, misma industria es otra manera de verlo, pero tienes que encontrar esa intersección única donde claramente estés entre los mejores que saben hacer eso.
context: Lenny asks Fareed for advice on how product managers can set up their careers to potentially become full-time advisors or consultants in the future. Fareed is explaining the importance of building the right balance of depth and breadth in your expertise - you need to be specialized enough to be truly valuable, but not so narrow that you can only help one type of company or solve one specific problem.
vocabulary_highlights: top tier, unique intersection

speaker: Farhan Thawar
text: If you do the hard path and it doesn't work, actually you still win because you've now done something hard. You've probably worked with smart people. You've learned something along the way that is valuable. I meet lots of job seekers. I go, what are you doing to try to find a job? Are you really learning anything from sending out 10 resumes a day? Why don't you look at the API Docs and build something? Even if you don't get a job at Shopify, you've learned something.
text_ko: 어려운 길을 택해서 잘 안 되더라도 사실 이긴 거예요. 왜냐하면 어려운 걸 해봤고, 아마 똑똑한 사람들과 함께 일해봤을 거고, 그 과정에서 가치 있는 걸 배웠기 때문이에요. 구직자들을 많이 만나는데 저는 항상 묻죠, 취업을 위해 지금 뭘 하고 계세요? 하루에 이력서 10통씩 보내는 걸로 진짜 배우는 게 있나요? 왜 API 문서(API Docs)를 보고 직접 뭔가 만들어보지 않아요? 설령 쇼피파이(Shopify)에 못 가더라도 분명 배운 게 있을 거예요.
text_zh: 如果你选择了困难的路，就算最后没成功，其实你也是赢家，因为你已经做了一件有挑战性的事情。你可能和聪明人一起共事过，一路上肯定学到了有价值的东西。我见过很多找工作的人，我就问他们，你现在在做什么来找工作？每天投10份简历你真的能学到什么吗？为什么不去看看API文档，自己做点东西出来？就算最后没进Shopify，你也学到东西了啊。
text_es: Si tomas el camino difícil y no funciona, en realidad igual ganas porque ya hiciste algo complicado. Probablemente trabajaste con gente inteligente. Aprendiste algo en el proceso que tiene valor. Conozco muchas personas que buscan trabajo. Les pregunto, ¿qué estás haciendo para conseguir trabajo? ¿De verdad estás aprendiendo algo mandando 10 currículums al día? ¿Por qué no mejor revisas la documentación de APIs y construyes algo? Aunque no consigas trabajo en Shopify, ya aprendiste algo.
context: Lenny asks Farhan to explain his philosophy of choosing the harder path when deciding between options. Farhan explains that when you take the easy route and it fails, you learn nothing, but when you take the hard path and it fails, you still gain valuable skills and experience. He uses job searching as an example - instead of just sending out resumes, candidates should build something with a company's APIs to demonstrate skills and learn in the process.
vocabulary_highlights: hard path, along the way, API Docs

speaker: Farhan Thawar
text: I have been in many situations with many sharp people who have said to me, that's the stupidest fucking question I've ever heard. My goal there is not to annoy the person, but it's to understand the content.
text_ko: 저는 여러 상황에서 예리한 분들이 저에게 “이건 내가 들어본 것 중에 가장 어처구니없는 질문이야”라고 말하는 걸 많이 겪었어요. 제 목표는 그 사람을 짜증나게 하려는 게 아니라, 내용을 제대로 이해하려는 거예요.
text_zh: 我遇到过很多聪明人，他们会对我说，这是我听过的最蠢的问题了。但我的目的不是要惹他们生气，而是想真正搞懂这个事儿。
text_es: He estado en muchas situaciones con gente muy lista que me ha dicho: "esa es la pregunta más estúpida que he escuchado en mi puta vida". Mi objetivo ahí no es joder a la persona, sino entender realmente el contenido.
context: Lenny asks about Farhan's quote that looking stupid in public is his superpower. Farhan explains that he's comfortable asking questions that others might consider dumb because his priority is understanding the content rather than protecting his image. He shares that even successful business people have harshly criticized his questions, but he persists because learning is more important than appearing smart.
vocabulary_highlights: sharp people, stupidest fucking question, annoy the person

speaker: Farhan Thawar
text: They're mostly different people, but they're similar in one thing is that they haven't... they have an irrational view of what the world should look like over the next decade or so. They're very long-term thinkers, very rational in that they'll look and say, 'Hey, in 10, 15, 20, 25 years, this is what the world's going to look like.' And I'm not good at seeing that vision, but I'm good at trying to move towards that vision 1% a week.
text_ko: 대부분 서로 다른 사람들이지만, 한 가지 닮은 점이 있어요. 앞으로 10년쯤 동안 세상이 어떻게 돼야 한다고 좀 비현실적인 관점을 가지고 있다는 거예요. 그 사람들은 굉장히 장기적 사고를 하는 사람들(long-term thinkers)이라서, 10년, 15년, 20년, 25년 뒤에는 세상이 이렇게 될 거라고 이성적으로 말해요. 저는 그런 비전(vision)을 한눈에 보는 건 잘 못하지만, 대신 그 비전을 향해 매주 1%씩이라도 움직이려고 해요.
text_zh: 这些人大部分都不一样，但有一个共同点，就是他们对未来十年左右世界应该是什么样子，都有一种"不理性"的看法。他们都是很有长远眼光的人，很理性地会说："嘿，十年、十五年、二十年、二十五年后，世界就会是这个样子。"我看不到那种远景，但我擅长朝着那个远景每周前进1%。
text_es: Son personas muy diferentes en su mayoría, pero tienen algo en común: tienen una visión... digamos, irracional de cómo debería verse el mundo en la próxima década. Son pensadores a muy largo plazo, muy racionales en el sentido de que analizan y dicen: "Oye, en 10, 15, 20, 25 años, así va a ser el mundo." Y yo no soy bueno para ver esa visión, pero sí soy bueno tratando de avanzar hacia esa visión un 1% cada semana.
context: Lenny points out that Farhan has worked for a different billionaire each decade of his career and asks what connects these successful leaders. Farhan explains that while these leaders are different people, they share the ability to envision how the world will look decades in the future. He recognizes that his strength is execution - moving toward their vision incrementally - rather than having the visionary ability himself.
vocabulary_highlights: irrational view, long-term thinkers, 1% a week, move towards that vision
topics: Leadership & Management, Strategy & Planning, Career Development

speaker: Farhan Thawar
text: It is the most underutilized management tool in engineering, bar none. It is just not used as much as it could be. So pair programming, for those who don't know, it's two people on one computer. The throughput limiter is not hands-on keyboard. The limiter is where is the good elegant solution? How do we think through the problem and build the right solution for the problem at hand?
text_ko: 엔지니어링에서 이보다 덜 활용되는 관리 도구는 없어요, 정말로. 그냥 충분히 쓰이고 있지 않아요. 페어 프로그래밍(pair programming)은, 모르는 분들을 위해 말하면 두 사람이 한 대의 컴퓨터에서 함께 일하는 방식이에요. 처리량 병목(throughput limiter)은 키보드를 직접 두드리는 사람(hands-on keyboard)이 아니에요. 진짜 제약은 어디에 좋은 우아한 해결책(elegant solution)이 있느냐예요. 문제를 어떻게 생각해서 당면한 문제에 맞는 올바른 해결책을 만드는지가 중요해요.
text_zh: 这绝对是工程管理中最被低估的工具，没有之一。真的是远远没有发挥出它应有的作用。结对编程(pair programming)，不了解的朋友我解释一下，就是两个人用一台电脑写代码。其实效率的瓶颈根本不在于谁在敲键盘，真正的瓶颈是怎么找到那个优雅的解决方案，怎么把问题想透彻，然后针对手头的问题做出最合适的方案。
text_es: Es la herramienta de gestión más subutilizada en ingeniería, sin lugar a dudas. Simplemente no se usa tanto como debería. Entonces, la programación en pareja (pair programming), para quienes no la conocen, son dos personas trabajando en una sola computadora. El cuello de botella no está en quién tiene las manos en el teclado. La limitante está en encontrar esa solución elegante y buena. ¿Cómo pensamos el problema y construimos la solución correcta para lo que tenemos entre manos?
context: Lenny asks why Farhan is such a big advocate for pair programming, since it seems counterintuitive to have two engineers working on one computer. Farhan argues that pair programming is incredibly underused in engineering management. He explains that the bottleneck in software development isn't typing speed but finding the right solution to problems - and two people working together are much better at this than one person alone.
vocabulary_highlights: underutilized management tool, bar none, throughput limiter, hands-on keyboard, elegant solution, problem at hand

speaker: Farhan Thawar
text: Everyone says, 'Oh yeah, work hard and do more hours when you're young, whatever.' I'm like, 'What if you just did more per minute?' Like quickly get through things. I think there's another unintuitive fact is that people who are really good can actually output high-quality collateral quickly.
text_ko: 사람들은 다들 '젊을 때 열심히 일하고 근무 시간 더 늘려라'고 하죠. 저는 '그럼 분당 더 많이 해보면 어때요?'라고 해요. 일을 빠르게 처리하는 거죠. 또 의외인 건, 진짜 잘하는 사람들은 고품질의 영업·마케팅 자료(collateral)를 빠르게 만들어낼 수 있다는 거예요.
text_zh: 大家都说"趁年轻多加班多干活什么的"，我就想，你为什么不试试提高每分钟的效率呢？就是快速把事情搞定。还有个违反常理的现象，真正厉害的人其实能又快又好地产出高质量的材料。
text_es: Todo el mundo dice, "Ah sí, trabaja duro y echa más horas cuando eres joven, lo que sea." Yo pienso, "¿Y si simplemente rindieras más por minuto?" O sea, despachar las cosas rápido. Creo que hay otra cosa contraintuitiva y es que la gente que es realmente buena sí puede producir material de alta calidad rápidamente.
context: Lenny asks about creating intensity in organizations, specifically Farhan's philosophy of expending more energy per hour rather than working longer hours. Farhan challenges the conventional wisdom of working more hours when young, suggesting instead that people should focus on accomplishing more within the same timeframe. He points out that highly skilled people can produce quality work faster, not just work longer.
vocabulary_highlights: more per minute, unintuitive fact, high-quality collateral

speaker: Farhan Thawar
text: We can always almost find a million-plus lines of code to delete, which is insane. But at the same time, I applaud the teams for going after the cruft and the code base. And everything gets easier, right? Code loads faster. It's easier to understand.
text_ko: 우리는 거의 항상 백만 줄이 넘는 코드를 지워도 될 부분을 찾아낼 수 있어요. 정말 말도 안 돼요. 하지만 동시에 그런 쓸데없는 코드(cruft)와 코드베이스(code base)를 정리하러 나선 팀들은 정말 칭찬받아 마땅해요. 그러면 모든 게 더 쉬워져요. 코드 로딩도 빨라지고 이해하기도 쉬워져요.
text_zh: 我们几乎总能找到上百万行可以删掉的代码，这简直太疯狂了。不过同时我也得给团队点个赞，他们敢于清理那些冗余代码和代码库。然后你知道吗，一切都变得更容易了，对吧？代码跑得更快，也更好理解了。
text_es: Siempre podemos encontrar más de un millón de líneas de código para eliminar, lo cual es una locura. Pero a la vez, aplaudo a los equipos por ir tras toda esa basura (cruft) y limpiar la base de código. Y todo se vuelve más fácil, ¿no? El código carga más rápido. Es más fácil de entender.
context: Lenny asks about Shopify's initiative to delete code and simplify their codebase. Farhan explains that they have a Delete Code Club and regularly find millions of lines of code that can be removed during hack days. He sees this as beneficial because removing unnecessary code makes everything faster and easier to understand, though he acknowledges it might seem counterintuitive to celebrate deleting work.
vocabulary_highlights: million-plus lines, going after the cruft, code base

speaker: Garrett Lord
speaker_expertise: Growth Strategy, Community Building, Career Development
text: Generally speaking, anytime that you're interacting with a model and you're asking it to do really advanced things, and it's not performing your expectations, like somewhere there's probably an expert that is the top mind in that domain working directly for the best researchers in the world at the Frontier Labs trying to understand and go through the scientific iteration process of how to make that better.
text_ko: 보통은 모델(model)하고 상호작용하면서 정말 고난도 작업을 시키는데 기대만큼 성능이 안 나오면, 어딘가엔 아마 그 분야의 최고 전문가가 있고요. 그 전문가는 세계 최고 연구자들과 함께 프론티어 랩(Frontier Labs)에서 직접 문제를 파악하고 어떻게 개선할지 과학적 반복 개선 과정(scientific iteration process)을 거치며 연구하고 있을 가능성이 커요.
text_zh: 一般来说，当你在使用模型，让它做一些特别高端的任务，但它的表现达不到你的期望时，背后肯定有这个领域的顶级专家，在世界最好的前沿实验室(Frontier Labs)里跟最牛的研究人员一起合作，通过科学的迭代过程来琢磨怎么把这个问题解决得更好。
text_es: En términos generales, cada vez que estás trabajando con un modelo y le pides que haga cosas realmente avanzadas, y no está cumpliendo con tus expectativas, seguramente hay un experto en algún lugar que es la mente más brillante en ese campo, trabajando directamente con los mejores investigadores del mundo en los Frontier Labs, tratando de entender y llevando a cabo todo el proceso de iteración científica para mejorar esa función.
context: Lenny asks if there's anything else about the data labeling field that people don't fully understand. Garrett explains how AI labs are constantly working to improve model performance across different domains. When users experience limitations with AI models in advanced areas, there are likely domain experts already working with top researchers at frontier AI labs to address those specific weaknesses through a scientific process of iteration and improvement.
vocabulary_highlights: performing your expectations, top mind in that domain, frontier labs, scientific iteration process

speaker: Garrett Lord
speaker_expertise: Growth Strategy, Community Building, Career Development
text: I think if you viewed your research team and your model building team, and the experiments they're running to be really the cornerstone of how you're improving, you probably wouldn't want the latest research of what you're trying to work on being invested in by a peer. We like to say the only moat in human data is access to an audience.
text_ko: 연구팀과 모델 구축 팀, 그리고 그들이 진행하는 실험이 개선의 핵심이라고 생각한다면, 아마도 당신이 작업하고 있는 최신 연구가 동료에게 투자되는 걸 원하지 않을 거예요. 우리는 인간 데이터에서 유일한 방어선은 청중에 대한 접근이라고 자주 말하곤 해요.
text_zh: 我觉得如果你把研究团队、模型搭建团队，还有他们跑的那些实验当作是你们改进提升的核心基石，那你肯定不希望竞争对手也投资你正在研究的最新方向吧。我们常说，在人类数据这块，唯一的护城河就是能接触到用户群体。
text_es: Mira, si consideras que tu equipo de investigación y tu equipo de desarrollo de modelos, y los experimentos que están haciendo, son realmente la base de cómo vas mejorando, probablemente no querrías que la investigación más reciente en lo que estás trabajando esté siendo financiada por un competidor. Nos gusta decir que la única ventaja competitiva real en datos humanos es tener acceso a una audiencia.
context: Lenny asks about Scale AI being acquired by Meta and whether this creates opportunities for other companies in the data labeling space. Garrett explains why AI labs prefer working with independent data providers rather than competitors. He emphasizes that in the human data labeling business, the key competitive advantage is having direct access to the right experts, rather than relying on expensive recruitment and advertising to find qualified people.
vocabulary_highlights: cornerstone of how you're improving, invested in by a peer, only moat in human data

speaker: Garrett Lord
speaker_expertise: Growth Strategy, Community Building, Career Development
text: The huge advantage that we've had and why we've resonated so fast in the marketplace is we built a decade of trust with 18 million people, and they trust us, and we built a ton of brand affinity, and they use Handshake, and they have an active profile, and we have a ton of information around their academic performance and what they've done in school.
