text_ko: 우리가 가진 큰 장점이자 시장에서 이렇게 빠르게 반응을 얻은 이유는 10년 동안 1,800만 명과 쌓아온 신뢰 덕분이에요. 사람들은 우리를 믿고 있고, 브랜드에 대한 호감(brand affinity)도 많이 쌓였어요. 그들은 핸드쉐이크(Handshake)를 사용하고 활동적인 프로필을 가지고 있으며, 학업 성과나 학교에서 해온 활동에 대한 정보도 방대한 양으로 가지고 있어요.
text_zh: 我们最大的优势，也是为什么能在市场上这么快打响的原因，就是我们花了十年时间跟1800万用户建立了信任关系，他们信任我们，而且我们积累了超强的品牌黏性(brand affinity)，他们都在用Handshake，档案也很活跃，我们掌握了大量他们学习成绩和在校表现的数据。
text_es: La ventaja enorme que hemos tenido y por qué hemos conectado tan rápido en el mercado es que construimos una década de confianza con 18 millones de personas, confían en nosotros, creamos un montón de afinidad con la marca, usan Handshake, tienen un perfil activo, y tenemos muchísima información sobre su rendimiento académico y lo que han hecho en la universidad.
context: Garrett explains why Handshake has been so successful in the data labeling market compared to competitors. While other companies spend millions on advertising and recruiting to find experts, Handshake leveraged their existing decade-old platform that already had relationships with 18 million students and professionals. This existing trust and detailed user profiles gave them a massive competitive advantage in quickly scaling their expert network.
vocabulary_highlights: resonated so fast in the marketplace, brand affinity, ton of information around

speaker: Garrett Lord
speaker_expertise: Growth Strategy, Community Building, Career Development
text: We're the largest expert network in the world. We have more PhDs, 500,000 of them use Handshake than any other platform. We have three million master students who are in school or alumni. And so, we started to see all what I would call middleman companies reaching out to us saying, 'Can we recruit your PhDs and master's students?'
text_ko: 우리는 세계에서 가장 큰 전문가 네트워크예요. 50만 명의 박사님들이 Handshake를 사용하고 있어서 다른 플랫폼보다 더 많아요. 그리고 현재 재학 중이거나 졸업한 석사 학생이 300만 명이나 있어요. 그래서 중개업체들이 우리에게 연락해서 '우리의 박사님들과 석사 학생들을 모집할 수 있을까요?'라고 물어보는 경우가 많아졌어요.
text_zh: 我们是全球最大的专家网络。我们平台上有五十万博士在用Handshake，比其他任何平台都多。还有三百万硕士生，包括在校生和毕业生。所以呢，我们开始看到很多中介公司找上门来，问我们"能不能让我们招你们的博士和硕士？"
text_es: Somos la red de expertos más grande del mundo. Tenemos más doctores que nadie, 500,000 de ellos usan Handshake más que cualquier otra plataforma. Tenemos tres millones de estudiantes de maestría que están estudiando o ya son egresados. Y entonces empezamos a ver que todas estas empresas intermediarias (middleman companies) nos contactaban diciéndonos: '¿Podemos reclutar a sus doctores y estudiantes de maestría?'
context: Garrett describes how Handshake discovered the opportunity in AI data labeling. As the demand shifted from generalist workers to experts for training AI models, companies began approaching Handshake to recruit from their massive network of PhD and master's degree holders. This led them to realize they could cut out these middleman companies and serve the AI labs directly while providing a better experience for their users.
vocabulary_highlights: middleman companies, reaching out to us

speaker: Garrett Lord
speaker_expertise: Growth Strategy, Community Building, Career Development
text: There will never be a time like this. I've never seen anything like it. I doubt I'll ever feel anything like this in business again where there's unlimited demand. How do you make sure that three months from now, six months, you have no regrets? Get on the plane to go talk to a customer, make the late night push, check the data six times over again.
text_ko: 지금 같은 순간은 다시 오지 않을 거예요. 저도 이런 걸 본 적이 없고요. 수요가 끝없이 쏟아지는 이 상황을 비즈니스에서 다시 만나게 될지 잘 모르겠어요. 3개월, 6개월 뒤에 후회하지 않으려면 어떻게 해야 할까요? 고객 만나러 비행기 타고 가고, 밤을 새워서라도 밀어붙이고, 데이터를 몇 번이고 꼼꼼히 다시 확인하세요.
text_zh: 这种机会绝对是千载难逢的。我从来没见过这样的情况，估计以后在商场上也不太可能再遇到需求如此爆炸的时候了。怎么确保三个月后、半年后不会后悔呢？该飞就飞，去见客户；该熬夜就熬夜，拼一把；数据该检查几遍就检查几遍，不能马虎。
text_es: Nunca va a haber un momento como este. Jamás he visto algo así. Dudo que vuelva a sentir algo parecido en los negocios, donde hay una demanda ilimitada. ¿Cómo te aseguras de que dentro de tres meses, seis meses, no te vayas a arrepentir? Súbete al avión para ir a hablar con un cliente, haz ese último esfuerzo hasta tarde, revisa los datos seis veces más.
context: Garrett shares the motto 'leave nothing to chance' that his team adopted while building their AI data labeling business. He emphasizes the unprecedented nature of the current AI opportunity, where there's essentially unlimited demand for high-quality training data. This mindset drove his team to work extremely hard - including nights and weekends - to ensure they could capitalize on this once-in-a-lifetime market opportunity.
vocabulary_highlights: unlimited demand, have no regrets, make the late night push, check the data six times over again

speaker: Garrett Lord
speaker_expertise: Growth Strategy, Community Building, Career Development
text: That's not what we're hearing from our employers, this is just enabling human beings to be even more productive. You used to put a Google Search on a skill on your resume because you grew up with Google. Being AI native, young people are at a huge advantage.
text_ko: 고용주들한테서 듣는 얘기는 그게 아니에요. 이건 사람들을 훨씬 더 생산적으로 만들어 주는 도구일 뿐이에요. 예전에는 구글 검색(Google Search)을 이력서에 기술로 적곤 했는데, 구글과 함께 자라서 그랬죠. AI 네이티브(AI native)인 젊은 세대는 훨씬 더 큰 이점을 가지고 있어요.
text_zh: 我们从雇主那边听到的可不是这样，AI其实是让人变得更高效了。以前你们那代人简历上还会写"熟练使用Google搜索"，因为你们是跟着Google长大的。现在这些年轻人从小就接触AI，他们占大便宜了。
text_es: Eso no es lo que escuchamos de nuestros empleadores, esto simplemente permite que las personas sean aún más productivas. Antes ponías "búsqueda en Google" como habilidad en tu currículum porque creciste con Google. Al ser nativos de la IA (AI native), los jóvenes tienen una ventaja enorme.
context: Lenny asks about the tension between students training AI models that might eventually replace entry-level jobs. Garrett pushes back on fears about job displacement, explaining that employers using Handshake aren't reducing hiring. Instead, AI is making workers more productive, similar to how previous generations became skilled with Google search. He argues that young people who grow up using AI tools naturally will have significant advantages in the job market.
vocabulary_highlights: AI native, at a huge advantage

speaker: Gaurav Misra
speaker_expertise: Consumer Products, Engineering Leadership, User Experience
text: I actually think as a startup your job is to take on technical debt because that is how you operate faster than a bigger company. Bigger companies don't take on technical debt, they pay it usually right away, or they're paying back technical debt from the days when they were a startup.
text_ko: 솔직히 스타트업이라면 기술 부채(technical debt)를 어느 정도 감수하는 게 일이에요. 그게 더 큰 회사보다 빨리 움직일 수 있는 방법이거든요. 큰 회사들은 보통 기술 부채를 안 떠안고 바로 갚아버리거나, 예전 스타트업 시절에 쌓인 기술 부채를 지금 갚고 있는 경우가 많아요.
text_zh: 我觉得作为创业公司，你就应该承担技术债务(technical debt)，因为这样你才能比大公司跑得更快。大公司不会承担技术债务，他们通常马上就把债还了，要么就是在还他们创业时期欠下的技术债务。
text_es: En realidad creo que como startup tu trabajo es asumir deuda técnica (technical debt) porque así es como puedes operar más rápido que una empresa grande. Las empresas grandes no asumen deuda técnica, la pagan inmediatamente por lo general, o están pagando la deuda técnica de cuando eran startups.
context: Lenny asks Gaurav about how their team handles longer-term projects and backend infrastructure when they're shipping features every week. Gaurav explains their approach to managing technical debt strategically. He argues that startups should intentionally take on technical debt to move faster than larger competitors, viewing it as leverage similar to financial debt that allows you to build products you couldn't otherwise create with a small team.
vocabulary_highlights: take on technical debt, pay it usually right away, paying back technical debt

speaker: Gaurav Misra
speaker_expertise: Consumer Products, Engineering Leadership, User Experience
text: We have what we think of as the public roadmap. This is basically what people have asked us for. There's all these surface areas where we receive user feedback, but these are all features that every competitor knows about. If a user is asking us for it, they're asking everybody for it. It's not going to be a game changer in terms of winning against your competition. So we have a second roadmap which we think of as a secret roadmap.
text_ko: 저희에겐 공개 로드맵(public roadmap)이 있어요. 기본적으로 사람들이 요청해온 것들이고, 사용자 피드백(user feedback)이 들어오는 겉으로 드러나는 여러 영역(surface areas)이 있는데 그런 기능들은 사실 모든 경쟁사(competitors)가 다 알고 있어요. 사용자가 우리한테 요청하는 건 결국 다들 똑같이 요청하는 거라 경쟁에서 판도를 바꿀 결정적 요소(game changer)는 되지 못해요. 그래서 저희는 비공개 로드맵(secret roadmap)도 따로 갖고 있어요.
text_zh: 我们有一个公开路线图，基本上就是用户要求我们做的那些功能。我们有很多渠道收集用户反馈，但这些功能每个竞争对手都知道。用户跟我们提的需求，肯定也会跟其他家提。光做这些是没法在竞争中脱颖而出的，不会成为制胜法宝。所以我们还有第二个路线图，我们叫它秘密路线图。
text_es: Tenemos lo que llamamos el roadmap público. Básicamente es lo que la gente nos ha pedido. Hay un montón de puntos donde recibimos feedback de usuarios, pero todas estas son funcionalidades que todos los competidores ya conocen. Si un usuario nos lo está pidiendo a nosotros, se lo está pidiendo a todo el mundo. No va a ser algo que cambie las reglas del juego para ganarle a tu competencia. Entonces tenemos un segundo roadmap que consideramos nuestro roadmap secreto.
context: Lenny asks about unique aspects of how Gaurav's team operates and builds products. Gaurav describes their dual roadmap system - one public roadmap based on user requests that competitors also know about, and a secret roadmap containing innovative ideas that users haven't asked for. The secret roadmap contains features that could revolutionize user behavior and provide competitive advantages since competitors don't know about them.
vocabulary_highlights: surface areas, game changer, secret roadmap

speaker: Gaurav Misra
speaker_expertise: Consumer Products, Engineering Leadership, User Experience
text: He surrounded himself with the design team. That was sort of the central team in the company. And the design team was like 10, 12 people. Basically, pretty small, even at 5, 6,000 employees it was that small still. These weren't your sort of average designers. These were designers who were actually PMs as well. That's what the secret sauce was.
text_ko: 그는 디자인 팀을 곁에 두었어요. 그 팀이 회사에서 사실상 중심 팀 같은 역할이었어요. 디자인 팀은 대략 10명에서 12명 정도였고, 직원 수가 5천, 6천 명이 돼도 여전히 그 정도로 작았어요. 이건 평범한 디자이너들이 아니라 실제로 프로덕트 매니저(PM)이기도 한 디자이너들이었어요. 그게 바로 핵심 비결(secret sauce)이었어요.
text_zh: 他身边都是设计团队的人，这个团队算是公司的核心。设计团队也就10个、12个人，规模挺小的，就算公司有五六千员工了，设计团队还是那么点人。这些可不是一般的设计师，他们同时也是产品经理(PM)，这就是他们的杀手锏。
text_es: Se rodeó del equipo de diseño. Ese era como el equipo central de la empresa. Y el equipo de diseño eran unas 10, 12 personas. Básicamente, bastante pequeño, incluso con 5 o 6 mil empleados seguía siendo así de chico. Estos no eran diseñadores comunes y corrientes. Eran diseñadores que también funcionaban como PMs (product managers). Ahí estaba la salsa secreta.
context: Lenny asks what made Snap successful as a consumer social product. Gaurav explains Snap's unique organizational structure where CEO Evan Spiegel maintained granular control through a small central design team. At 5,000-6,000 employees, the design team was only 10-12 people who functioned as both designers and product managers, giving the CEO direct oversight of every user-facing change in the app.
vocabulary_highlights: surrounded himself, secret sauce, granular control

speaker: Gaurav Misra
speaker_expertise: Consumer Products, Engineering Leadership, User Experience
text: One of the insights that we had, which was unique was as the company gets bigger, you can actually create alignment by causing internal virality. If there's enough people in the company, it actually starts acting like a consumer base might. If you share something interesting with someone, they will share it with somebody else because they think it's interesting and you can actually create virality inside a company.
text_ko: 우리가 얻은 독특한 통찰 중 하나는, 회사가 커질수록 내부 확산(internal virality)을 통해 자연스럽게 방향이 맞춰진다는 거예요. 직원 수가 충분히 많아지면 회사가 소비자층(consumer base)처럼 행동하기 시작해요. 누군가에게 흥미로운 걸 공유하면 그 사람이 흥미를 느껴 다른 사람에게 또 공유하고, 회사 내부에서 바이럴(virality)이 생겨요.
text_zh: 我们有个挺独特的发现，就是公司越做越大的时候，你其实可以通过内部的病毒式传播(internal virality)来让大家步调一致。如果公司人够多的话，其实就跟消费者群体差不多了。你跟别人分享个有意思的东西，他们觉得确实不错，就会再传给其他人，这样在公司内部就能形成病毒式传播(virality)的效果。
text_es: Una de las cosas que descubrimos, y que fue algo único, es que cuando la empresa crece, en realidad puedes crear alineación generando viralidad interna. Si hay suficiente gente en la compañía, empieza a comportarse como si fuera una base de consumidores. Si compartes algo interesante con alguien, esa persona se lo va a compartir a otra porque le parece interesante, y así puedes crear viralidad dentro de la empresa.
context: Gaurav describes the design engineering function he created at Snap to help the company continue innovating at scale. He explains how they solved the alignment problem that typically plagues large organizations. Instead of traditional stakeholder management, they discovered they could create internal virality - when prototype products were interesting enough, employees would naturally share them throughout the company, creating organic excitement and alignment.
vocabulary_highlights: internal virality, acting like a consumer base, create virality inside a company

speaker: Gaurav Misra
speaker_expertise: Consumer Products, Engineering Leadership, User Experience
text: I think PM is a very valuable function. I think it may be actually, and maybe I'll get roasted for this, but I think at the end of the day, not hiring PMs at Snap might've been one of those decisions where it actually succeeded despite that and because someone needs to do that work. If you don't have enough people to do it, then nobody truly owns it and then it doesn't really happen.
text_ko: 저는 프로덕트 매니저(PM)가 정말 가치 있는 역할이라고 생각해요. 이 얘기 때문에 까일 수도 있지만, 솔직히 말하면 스냅에서 PM을 안 뽑은 결정이 오히려 잘된 선택이었을 수도 있다고 봐요. 결국 그 일을 누군가는 해야 하고, 사람이 충분하지 않으면 아무도 진짜로 그 책임을 지지 않아서 일이 제대로 안 돌아가거든요.
text_zh: 我觉得产品经理(PM)这个岗位真的很有价值。可能我这么说会被人喷，但我觉得说到底，Snap不招PM可能是那种看起来成功了但其实有问题的决定，因为总得有人干这活儿。如果没有足够的人手去做，那就没人真正负责这事儿，最后就搞不成了。
text_es: Creo que PM es una función súper valiosa. De hecho, creo que puede ser que... y a lo mejor me van a crucificar por esto, pero creo que al final del día, no contratar PMs en Snap pudo haber sido una de esas decisiones donde la cosa funcionó a pesar de eso, porque alguien tiene que hacer ese trabajo. Si no tienes suficiente gente para hacerlo, entonces nadie realmente se hace cargo y al final no pasa nada.
context: Lenny asks why Gaurav's current company operates with traditional PMs, engineers, and designers instead of the hybrid roles that worked at Snap. Gaurav reflects critically on Snap's no-PM approach, suggesting it may have been successful despite this structure rather than because of it. He emphasizes that the PM work still needs to be done by someone, and without clear ownership, important product management tasks may not happen at all.
vocabulary_highlights: get roasted for this, succeeded despite that, nobody truly owns it

speaker: Gaurav Misra
speaker_expertise: Consumer Products, Engineering Leadership, User Experience
text: I think from a user acquisition/marketing perspective, in a world five or seven years ago, if you were making something novel and you went to users and it was like, 'Oh, we got something better.' People are going to be like, 'Well, whatever. Everybody says they got something better. I don't care.' But today, you can go and just say, 'We've rethought this thing with AI.' And a bunch of people will just be like, 'Well, how?' Or 'Maybe I should check this out.'
text_ko: 사용자 확보/마케팅(user acquisition/marketing) 관점에서 보면, 5~7년 전쯤엔 뭔가 새롭고 독창적인 걸 만들고 사용자한테 '우리가 더 나은 걸 만들었어요'라고 해도 사람들 반응이 '다들 다 더 낫다고 해요. 별로 신경 안 써요'였을 거예요. 근데 요즘엔 '이걸 인공지능(AI)으로 다시 설계했어요'라고만 해도 많은 사람이 '어떻게요?' '한번 써봐야겠다' 하고 반응해요.
text_zh: 我觉得从用户获取和营销的角度来看，要是在五六年前，如果你做了个新产品，跟用户说"嘿，我们这个更牛"，人家会想"得了吧，谁都这么说，我才不信呢。" 但现在不一样了，你只要说"我们用AI(人工智能)重新设计了这个东西"，很多人马上就会问"怎么个用法？"或者"我得去看看"。
text_es: Yo creo que desde el punto de vista de captación de usuarios y marketing, hace cinco o siete años, si estabas creando algo nuevo y le decías a los usuarios "Oye, tenemos algo mejor", la gente te respondía "Sí, claro. Todo el mundo dice que tiene algo mejor. Me da igual." Pero hoy en día, puedes llegar y simplemente decir "Hemos repensado esto con IA" y un montón de gente va a reaccionar como "¿Ah sí? ¿Cómo?" o "A lo mejor debería echarle un vistazo."
context: Lenny asks about the challenge of getting people to pay attention to new products when it's so easy to build things now. Gaurav explains how the current AI moment creates unique opportunities for user acquisition. Unlike the past when claiming to have 'something better' was met with skepticism, today simply mentioning AI rethinking of existing solutions generates genuine curiosity and willingness to try new products.
vocabulary_highlights: user acquisition, rethought this thing with AI, check this out

speaker: Geoff Charles
speaker_expertise: B2B SaaS, Product Design, Leadership Development
text: So when I joined, we were about 10-ish folks, about eight engineers, and in three months, we built a competitor to Amex. Six months after that, we built a competitor to Expensify, both publicly traded companies. We hit a hundred million in annual revenue. I think we were under at that point, 50 total in the R&D department, less than four engineers and three PMs. And then we started expanding into accounts payable. It was three engineers, one designer, one PM three months, and they hit out of the park. And that product is moving in billions of dollars a year.
text_ko: 제가 합류했을 때, 팀이 한 10명 정도였고, 그 중 8명이 엔지니어였어요. 3개월 만에 Amex의 경쟁 제품을 만들었고, 그로부터 6개월 후에는 Expensify의 경쟁 제품도 만들었죠. 두 회사 모두 상장된 회사인데, 우리는 연매출 1억 달러를 달성했어요. 그 당시 R&D 부서에는 50명도 안 되고, 엔지니어는 4명도 안 됐고 PM은 3명이었어요. 그리고 나서 우리는 외상 매출금(accounts payable) 쪽으로 확장을 시작했어요. 그때 엔지니어 3명, 디자이너 1명, PM 1명으로 3개월 만에 대박을 쳤죠. 그 제품은 연간 수십억 달러를 움직이고 있어요.
text_zh: 我刚加入的时候，团队大概就10个人左右，8个工程师。三个月内，我们就做出了一个能跟美国运通(Amex)竞争的产品。又过了六个月，我们又搞出了一个跟Expensify竞争的产品，这俩都是上市公司啊。我们做到了年收入一个亿美金。那时候我们整个研发部门还不到50个人，工程师不到4个，产品经理3个。后来我们开始拓展应付账款(accounts payable)业务，就3个工程师，1个设计师，1个产品经理，三个月时间，结果做得特别成功。这个产品现在一年能跑几十亿美金的流水。
text_es: Entonces cuando me uní, éramos como 10 personas, unos ocho ingenieros, y en tres meses armamos un competidor de Amex. Seis meses después, creamos un competidor de Expensify, ambas empresas que cotizan en bolsa. Llegamos a cien millones en ingresos anuales. Creo que en ese momento éramos menos de 50 en total en el departamento de I+D, menos de cuatro ingenieros y tres PMs. Y entonces empezamos a expandirnos a cuentas por pagar. Fueron tres ingenieros, un diseñador, un PM, tres meses, y la pegaron fuera del estadio. Y ese producto está moviendo miles de millones de dólares al año.
context: Lenny asks for concrete examples of what velocity actually looks like at Ramp beyond just saying they move fast. Geoff provides specific examples of how small teams at Ramp built competitors to major publicly traded companies in extremely short timeframes. He explains how they built products that compete with American Express and Expensify with minimal team sizes, and how they expanded into accounts payable with just a 5-person team that created a product processing billions of dollars annually.
vocabulary_highlights: hit out of the park
topics: Product Management, Leadership & Management, Starting a Company

speaker: Geoff Charles
speaker_expertise: B2B SaaS, Product Design, Leadership Development
text: There are very few people who are able to execute extremely well in more than one thing, and it's especially true for individual contributors. And so what I mean by single threaded is there's only one goal, one thread, that they're waking up in the morning to focus on. And in order to remove that, you basically need to remove anything else that they're being asked to do to just focus on that thing, whether it's any type of research or any type of production engineering or any type of process that's outside of that single goal.
text_ko: 여러 분야에서 아주 뛰어나게 실행할 수 있는 사람은 거의 없고, 특히 개인 기여자(individual contributors)에게는 더 그래요. 제가 '한 가지에만 집중하는(single-threaded)'이라고 말할 때는, 아침에 일어나서 오직 하나의 목표, 하나의 실무에만 집중한다는 뜻이에요. 그리고 그런 상태를 만들려면, 기본적으로 그들이 하라고 요청받는 다른 모든 일을 제거해야 해요 — 연구(research)이든 생산 엔지니어링(production engineering)이든, 그 단일 목표와 상관없는 어떤 업무나 프로세스도요.
text_zh: 能够在多个领域都做得特别出色的人真的很少，对于一线员工来说更是如此。我说的"单线程(single threaded)"就是指他们每天早上醒来只专注一个目标、一条线。要做到这一点，你基本上得把他们手上其他所有的活儿都拿掉，让他们就盯着这一件事，不管是什么研究工作、生产工程，还是跟这个核心目标无关的流程，统统都得清理掉。
text_es: Hay muy poca gente que puede ejecutar súper bien en más de una cosa a la vez, y esto es especialmente cierto para los colaboradores individuales. Cuando digo "single threaded" me refiero a que solo hay un objetivo, un hilo conductor, en el que se enfocan cuando se levantan por las mañanas. Y para lograr eso, básicamente necesitas quitarles todo lo demás que les estés pidiendo que hagan para que se concentren únicamente en esa cosa - ya sea cualquier tipo de investigación, ingeniería de producción, o cualquier proceso que esté fuera de ese objetivo único.
context: Lenny asks Geoff to explain what 'single-threaded teams' means in practice, as this was mentioned as a key ingredient for moving fast at Ramp. Geoff clarifies that single-threaded means each person has literally one goal or 'thread' they focus on when they wake up each morning. He explains this requires actively removing all other distractions, tasks, research, or processes that don't directly contribute to that single goal.
vocabulary_highlights: single threaded, individual contributors
topics: Product Management, Leadership & Management, Strategy & Planning

speaker: Geoff Charles
speaker_expertise: B2B SaaS, Product Design, Leadership Development
text: The first thing is we have market comparables, which is very exciting for us. So when you look at Bill.com, they're a publicly traded company, Expensify, publicly traded, or Concur or Coupa, these are all large players that are actually very motivating and largely de-risk some of the business decisions you're making. That's existing markets. We've also been able to create markets. Spend management was an actual market before we and other competitors jump into it.
text_ko: 우선 우리에겐 시장 비교 자료(market comparables)가 있다는 것만 해도 정말 고무적이에요. Bill.com이나 Expensify는 상장사고 Concur나 Coupa 같은 회사들도 모두 큰 플레이어라서 오히려 자극이 되고 우리가 내리는 여러 사업 결정의 리스크를 상당히 줄여줘요(de-risk). 그건 기존 시장(existing markets)에 해당해요. 또 저희는 시장을 만들어내기도 했어요. 스펜드 매니지먼트(spend management)라는 시장은 저희와 다른 경쟁사들이 뛰어들기 전부터 이미 실제로 존재하던 시장이었어요.
text_zh: 首先呢，我们有市场对标公司，这对我们来说特别振奋人心。你看像Bill.com，他们是上市公司，还有Expensify也上市了，或者Concur、Coupa这些，都是行业大玩家，真的很激励人，而且在很大程度上能降低我们做商业决策的风险。这些都是现有市场。我们也有能力去创造市场。支出管理(spend management)在我们和其他竞争对手进入之前，其实就已经是一个实实在在的市场了。
text_es: Lo primero es que tenemos comparables del mercado (market comparables), lo cual es súper emocionante para nosotros. Entonces cuando miras a Bill.com, que cotiza en bolsa, Expensify, que también cotiza públicamente, o Concur o Coupa, todos estos son jugadores grandes que realmente te motivan y en gran medida reducen el riesgo de las decisiones de negocio que estás tomando. Esos son mercados que ya existen. También hemos podido crear mercados. La gestión de gastos (spend management) ya era un mercado real antes de que nosotros y otros competidores nos metiéramos.
context: Lenny asks how Ramp finds the balance between setting ambitious goals versus impossible goals, referencing how other companies like Airbnb are known for very lofty targets. Geoff explains that having market comparables - existing publicly traded competitors like Bill.com and Expensify - makes ambitious goals feel more achievable and helps de-risk business decisions. He notes they can point to these successful companies as proof that large markets exist for their products.
vocabulary_highlights: market comparables, de-risk, jump into
topics: Strategy & Planning, Product Management, Leadership & Management

speaker: Geoff Charles
speaker_expertise: B2B SaaS, Product Design, Leadership Development
text: And oftentimes, more junior leaders, and I was certainly in that camp earlier on, kept focusing on the solutions and debating the right solution when in fact you should really be debating upstream of that. You should be debating the interpretation of data, you should be debating the hypotheses and the different ideas that you have there as to what's really going on or you should be debating the goals themselves.
text_ko: 종종 주니어 리더들(junior leaders)은—저도 예전엔 그랬어요—해결책에만 계속 집착해서 어떤 해결책이 옳은지 논쟁하곤 해요. 그런데 사실은 그보다 앞선 단계, 즉 상위 단계(upstream)에서 논의해야 해요. 데이터 해석(interpretation of data)을 두고 토론하고, 가설(hypotheses)이나 실제로 무슨 일이 일어나고 있는지에 대한 다양한 아이디어들을 검토하거나, 때로는 목표 자체(goals)를 다시 논의해야 해요.
text_zh: 很多时候，那些资历比较浅的领导者，我以前也是这样，总是盯着解决方案不放，老在那儿争论哪个方案更好。其实你应该往前推一步，应该争论的是对数据的理解，应该争论各种假设和想法——到底发生了什么，或者干脆争论目标本身对不对。
text_es: Y muchas veces, los líderes más junior, y yo claramente estaba en ese grupo al principio, se la pasaban enfocándose en las soluciones y discutiendo cuál era la solución correcta, cuando en realidad deberían estar debatiendo mucho antes de llegar ahí. Deberían estar debatiendo cómo interpretan los datos, deberían estar debatiendo las hipótesis y las diferentes ideas que tienen sobre qué está pasando realmente, o deberían estar debatiendo los objetivos mismos.
context: Lenny asks how Ramp operationalizes 'context over control' - empowering product teams without micromanaging them. Geoff explains that successful empowerment starts with alignment on goals, hypotheses, and data interpretation rather than debating specific solutions. He shares that junior leaders often make the mistake of focusing downstream on solutions when they should be focusing upstream on understanding the problem, data, and objectives first.
vocabulary_highlights: upstream of that, debating the hypotheses
topics: Leadership & Management, Product Management, Decision Making

speaker: Geoff Charles
speaker_expertise: B2B SaaS, Product Design, Leadership Development
text: We don't have a bug backlog. We fix every bug once they're surfaced almost. So it's part of the production engineer's job really just to fix those things. I think where we get to nuances, like user experience improvements, the metric there that I really look at is how many support tickets come in that were due to a customer being confused.
text_ko: 우리는 버그 백로그(bug backlog)가 없어요. 버그가 발견되면 거의 바로 고쳐요. 그래서 그런 것들을 고치는 건 사실 프로덕션 엔지니어(production engineer)의 업무 중 하나예요. 사용자 경험 개선(user experience improvements)처럼 미묘한 부분으로 가면, 제가 실제로 보는 지표는 고객이 혼란스러워해서 들어오는 지원 티켓(support tickets)의 수예요.
text_zh: 我们不会积压bug。基本上一发现问题就马上修，这其实就是生产工程师的活儿。但涉及到一些细节，比如用户体验优化这块，我主要看的指标就是有多少客服工单(support tickets)是因为用户搞不清楚操作才提交的。
text_es: No tenemos una acumulación de errores pendientes. Arreglamos casi todos los bugs en cuanto salen a la luz. Así que es parte del trabajo del ingeniero de producción simplemente solucionar esas cosas. Creo que donde entramos en matices, como mejoras en la experiencia del usuario (user experience), la métrica que realmente reviso es cuántos tickets de soporte nos llegan porque un cliente se confundió.
context: Lenny asks how teams should balance fixing quality issues and bugs versus hitting their main KPIs and goals. Geoff explains Ramp's approach to maintaining quality while moving fast - they don't maintain a traditional bug backlog but instead fix every bug immediately when it's discovered. He describes how they track customer confusion through support tickets as a key quality metric, and teams must stop shipping new features if this metric gets elevated.
vocabulary_highlights: bug backlog, get to nuances

speaker: Geoff Charles
speaker_expertise: B2B SaaS, Product Design, Leadership Development
text: Behind Ramp's velocity is a lot less the culture that I try to amplify, but a lot more the quality of the engineering and design talent candidly. And so I'm just standing really on their shoulders here. And so advice number one is ensure that from the top down there's an investment in R&D as a first-class citizen that you're paying upmarket, that you're hiring the best, that you're focusing on your engineering and tech brand, that you're bringing people who want to work there because they want to be empowered.
text_ko: Ramp의 속도 뒤에는 제가 강조하려는 문화보다 솔직히 말해서 엔지니어링과 디자인 인재의 품질이 훨씬 더 중요해요. 그래서 저는 그들의 어깨 위에 서 있는 거죠. 첫 번째 조언은 위에서부터 R&D에 대한 투자가 1급 시민으로 이루어지도록 해야 한다는 거예요. 즉, 좋은 인재를 채용하고, 엔지니어링과 기술 브랜드에 집중하며, 그곳에서 일하고 싶어 하는 사람들을 끌어들이는 것이죠. 그들이 권한을 부여받고 싶어 하니까요.
text_zh: Ramp能发展这么快，说实话主要不是因为我推动的企业文化，更多的是因为我们工程和设计团队的质量真的很高。我其实就是站在他们肩膀上而已。所以我的第一个建议就是，从上到下一定要把研发(R&D)当成头等大事来投资，该花的钱不能省，要招最好的人，要好好打造你的工程和技术品牌，要让那些真正想发挥才能的人愿意来你这里工作。
text_es: Detrás de la velocidad de Ramp hay mucho menos de la cultura que trato de impulsar, y mucho más de la calidad del talento en ingeniería y diseño, para ser honesto. Yo simplemente me apoyo en sus hombros aquí. Entonces mi primer consejo es asegurarte de que desde arriba haya una inversión en I+D como ciudadano de primera clase - que pagues bien en el mercado premium, que contrates a los mejores, que te enfoques en tu marca de ingeniería y tecnología, que traigas gente que quiera trabajar ahí porque quieren sentirse empoderados.
context: Lenny mentions that after their post about Ramp's approach, many CEOs started pressuring their PMs to move faster like Ramp, and asks for advice for PMs facing this pressure. Geoff clarifies that Ramp's velocity comes primarily from having exceptional engineering and design talent rather than just culture. He emphasizes that leaders must first invest in R&D as a priority, pay competitive rates, hire top talent, and build a strong engineering brand that attracts people who want to be empowered.
vocabulary_highlights: standing really on their shoulders, first-class citizen, paying upmarket
topics: Leadership & Management, Product Management, Strategy & Planning

speaker: Geoff Charles
speaker_expertise: B2B SaaS, Product Design, Leadership Development
text: I think the debate around working hard and burnout misses a key point, which is all about how much impact and how good you feel about the work that you're doing. And I think that for me, when I felt burnout, it was actually at the time where I had the lowest amount of velocity. But it was when I felt like I was putting a lot of effort into things that weren't actually moving.
text_ko: 열심히 일하는 것과 번아웃에 대한 논의는 중요한 한 가지를 놓치고 있는 것 같아요. 그건 바로 당신이 하는 일이 얼마나 임팩트(impact)가 있는지, 그리고 그 일에 대해 얼마나 만족감이나 보람을 느끼는지예요. 제 경우 번아웃을 느꼈을 때는 사실 진행 속도(velocity)가 가장 낮았을 때였어요. 많은 노력을 들이고 있다고 느꼈는데도 정작 일이 앞으로 나아가지 않을 때였죠.
text_zh: 我觉得大家在讨论努力工作和职业倦怠的时候，漏掉了一个关键点，就是你的工作到底能产生多大影响，以及你对自己做的事情感觉怎么样。对我来说，我感到倦怠的时候，其实恰恰是我工作效率最低的时候。那时候我感觉自己明明很努力，但做的那些事情根本没什么进展。
text_es: Creo que todo el debate sobre trabajar duro y el agotamiento se pierde un punto clave, que tiene que ver con el impacto que generas y qué tan bien te sientes con el trabajo que estás haciendo. Y para mí, cuando me sentí quemado, en realidad fue justo cuando tenía menos velocidad. Pero era cuando sentía que le estaba metiendo un montón de esfuerzo a cosas que realmente no estaban avanzando.
context: Lenny asks about burnout concerns given Ramp's intense focus on velocity and constant shipping. Geoff argues that the typical debate about working hard versus burnout misses a crucial point - burnout is more about lack of impact and meaningful progress than about working long hours. He shares that his personal experience with burnout occurred during periods of low velocity when he felt he was putting effort into work that wasn't actually moving the needle or creating meaningful outcomes.
vocabulary_highlights: misses a key point, moving the needle
topics: Work-Life Balance, Leadership & Management, Career Development

speaker: Geoffrey Moore
text: The tendency when you're in the chasm is, "I just need more customers. I should take any customer I could find," because we need revenue. It's like taking a match and running it back and forth under a log. It's not going to light the log. So how do you start a fire? Well, you start it by putting a little kindling, little crumpled up paper, and you hold the match in one place until the fire starts.
text_ko: 캐즘(chasm)에 빠져 있으면 흔히 "그냥 고객만 더 있으면 돼요. 찾을 수 있는 고객이면 누구든 받아야 해요"라고 생각해요. 매출이 필요하니까요. 그런데 그건 성냥을 들고 통나무 밑을 왔다 갔다 문지르는 것과 같아요. 통나무에 불이 붙지 않아요. 그럼 어떻게 불을 붙이나요? 작은 땔감(kindling)과 구겨 둔 종이 조금을 넣고 성냥을 한 곳에 대고 가만히 붙여서 불이 붙을 때까지 기다려야 해요.
text_zh: 当你处在鸿沟期(chasm)的时候，往往会想"我就是需要更多客户，只要能找到客户我都要"，因为我们需要收入嘛。但这就像拿根火柴在木头下面来回划，是点不着火的。那怎么生火呢？你得先放点引火物，比如揉成团的纸，然后把火柴固定在一个地方，一直烧到火真正燃起来。
text_es: La tendencia cuando estás en el abismo es pensar "necesito más clientes, debería aceptar cualquier cliente que encuentre" porque necesitamos ingresos. Es como tomar un fósforo y pasarlo de un lado a otro debajo de un tronco. No va a prender el tronco. Entonces, ¿cómo prendes un fuego? Bueno, lo prendes poniendo un poco de leña seca, papelitos arrugados, y mantienes el fósforo en un solo lugar hasta que el fuego comience.
context: Lenny asks Geoffrey about the importance of starting very focused with your initial target audience. Geoffrey explains why companies should resist the urge to go after any customer when trying to cross the chasm - the gap between early adopters and mainstream pragmatic customers. He uses a bonfire analogy to illustrate that scattered efforts won't create sustainable momentum, just as moving a match around won't light a log.
vocabulary_highlights: in the chasm, running it back and forth, little kindling

speaker: Geoffrey Moore
text: The Crossing the Chasm model is, "Can you create a viable repeatable business?" And in order to do that, you need to have an ecosystem of partners work with you in order to consolidate your position. Well, why would an ecosystem work with some startup that nobody's ever heard of? The answer would be if you had consolidated a market segment where you were number one.
text_ko: 크로싱 더 채즘(Crossing the Chasm) 모델은 '지속 가능하고 반복 가능한 비즈니스를 만들 수 있느냐?'를 묻는 모델이에요. 그렇게 하려면 파트너로 구성된 생태계(partner ecosystem)가 함께 움직여 회사의 입지를 공고히 해줘야 해요. 그런데 왜 아무도 모르는 스타트업과 그런 파트너 생태계가 굳이 협력하겠어요? 답은 그 스타트업이 특정 시장 세그먼트(market segment)에서 1위로 자리잡아야 한다는 거예요.
text_zh: 跨越鸿沟(Crossing the Chasm)模型其实就是在问，"你能不能打造一个可持续、可复制的生意？"要做到这一点，你得有一个生态圈，让各种合作伙伴愿意跟你一起干，这样才能巩固你的地位。但问题来了，凭什么这些生态伙伴要跟一个没人听过的小创业公司合作呢？答案很简单——除非你已经在某个细分市场里做到了老大的位置。
text_es: El modelo de Crossing the Chasm se trata de "¿Puedes crear un negocio viable y repetible?" Y para lograr eso, necesitas tener todo un ecosistema de socios que trabajen contigo para consolidar tu posición. Bueno, pero ¿por qué un ecosistema va a querer trabajar con una startup que nadie conoce? La respuesta sería si ya hubieras consolidado un segmento de mercado donde fueras el número uno.
context: Lenny asks why it's important to start focused with your initial target audience rather than going wide. Geoffrey explains the Crossing the Chasm framework - the challenge of moving from early visionary customers to mainstream pragmatic buyers. He emphasizes that ecosystems only form around market leaders, so startups must dominate a narrow segment first to attract partners and build sustainable competitive advantage.
vocabulary_highlights: viable repeatable business, consolidate your position, consolidated a market segment
topics: Product Management, Strategy & Planning, Growth & Marketing

speaker: Geoffrey Moore
text: Before the chasm, the customers you work with are people who say, "We believe what you believe." So in other words, they're on the same side. After the chasm, they say, "I'm not sure about that, but we need what you have." So transitioning from, "We believe what you believe," which is how you sell to visionaries to, "We need what you have," which is how you sell to pragmatists.
text_ko: 캐즘(chasm) 이전에 함께 일하는 고객들은 "당신이 믿는 걸 우리도 믿어요"라고 말하는 사람들이에요. 다시 말해 같은 편이죠. 캐즘(chasm) 이후에는 "그건 잘 모르겠지만, 당신이 가진 건 필요해요"라고 말해요. 즉 "당신이 믿는 걸 우리도 믿어요"라고 팔던 비전가들(visionaries)에게 파는 방식에서, "당신이 가진 게 필요해요"라고 팔아야 하는 실용주의자들(pragmatists)에게 파는 방식으로 바뀌는 거예요.
text_zh: 在跨越鸿沟之前，你服务的客户会说"我们跟你想的一样"。换句话说，他们跟你是一伙的。跨越鸿沟之后，他们会说"这个我还不太确定，但是我们需要你这个东西"。所以就是从"我们跟你想的一样"——这是你跟那些有远见的人做生意的方式，转变到"我们需要你这个东西"——这是你跟那些务实派做生意的方式。
text_es: Antes del abismo, los clientes con los que trabajas son personas que te dicen: "Creemos en lo mismo que tú". O sea, están de tu lado. Después del abismo, te dicen: "No estoy tan seguro de eso, pero necesitamos lo que tienes". Entonces es pasar de "Creemos en lo mismo que tú", que es como le vendes a los visionarios, a "Necesitamos lo que tienes", que es como le vendes a los pragmáticos.
context: Lenny explains the root of Crossing the Chasm - that pragmatists wait for references and social proof while visionaries want to use the future first. Geoffrey clarifies the fundamental shift in customer motivation across the technology adoption lifecycle. Early customers (visionaries) are excited about your vision and want to partner with you, while later customers (pragmatists) are primarily concerned with solving their practical business problems.
vocabulary_highlights: We believe what you believe, We need what you have, transitioning from
topics: Product Management, Growth & Marketing, Communication Skills

speaker: Geoffrey Moore
text: The key formula, and this is the formula... If there's one sort of takeaway from founders listening at this point, you want to have a target segment that is big enough to matter, small enough to lead and a good fit with your crown jewels. That's the formula.
text_ko: 핵심 공식이에요. 정말로, 공식은 이렇습니다. 지금 이걸 듣고 있는 창업자분들께 한 가지 꼭 기억하실 점이 있다면, 타깃 세그먼트(target segment)는 충분히 중요할 만큼 커야 하고, 여러분이 주도할 수 있을 만큼 작아야 하며, 여러분의 핵심 자산(crown jewels)과 잘 맞아야 해요. 그게 공식이에요.
text_zh: 关键的公式就是这样的...如果创始人们要从这里带走一个核心观点的话，就是你要找到一个目标细分市场(target segment)，这个市场要足够大、有意义，但又要足够小、你能做到头部，而且还要跟你的核心优势特别匹配。这就是公式。
text_es: La fórmula clave, y esta es la fórmula... Si hay algo que los fundadores que nos escuchan se tienen que llevar de aquí, es que necesitan un segmento objetivo que sea lo suficientemente grande como para que valga la pena, lo suficientemente pequeño como para poder dominarlo, y que encaje bien con sus joyas de la corona (crown jewels). Esa es la fórmula.
context: Lenny asks for advice on how startup founders should decide if their initial target audience is too wide and how to narrow it down effectively. Geoffrey provides his core formula for selecting the right beachhead market when crossing the chasm. He explains that founders need to balance market size with their ability to dominate that segment, while ensuring their unique capabilities match the market's needs.
vocabulary_highlights: big enough to matter, small enough to lead, crown jewels

speaker: Geoffrey Moore
text: You're looking for the 10th one. The 10th one is one who says, "I'm so tired of the status quo. I'm looking for people that are visionary like me. I like talking to you better than I like talking to my peers because you're different and I want to be different. I want to leapfrog the world, and these people just want to stay on the escalator."
text_ko: 당신이 찾는 건 바로 열 번째 사람이에요. 그 사람은 이렇게 말해요. "저는 현상 유지(status quo)에 너무 지쳤어요. 저처럼 비전 있는 사람들을 찾고 있어요. 동료들하고 얘기하는 것보다 당신과 얘기하는 게 더 좋아요. 당신은 달라서 저도 달라지고 싶거든요. 세계 시장에서 한 발 앞서 도약(leapfrog)하고 싶어요. 반면 어떤 사람들은 그냥 에스컬레이터에 올라탄 채 가만히 있으려 해요."
text_zh: 你要找的是第十个人。第十个人会说："我真的受够了现状了。我在找和我一样有远见的人。我更愿意跟你聊天，而不是跟我那些同行聊，因为你不一样，我也想变得不一样。我想实现跨越式发展，而那些人只想待在舒适圈里原地踏步。"
text_es: Buscas al décimo. El décimo es el que te dice: "Ya estoy harto del status quo. Busco gente visionaria como yo. Me gusta más hablar contigo que con mis colegas porque eres diferente y yo quiero ser diferente. Quiero saltar por encima del mundo, y esta gente solo quiere quedarse en la escalera mecánica."
context: Lenny asks about the common advice to avoid working with big companies because they'll push you around and force custom development. Geoffrey explains how to identify the right type of executive sponsor at large companies. He describes the persona-based approach to finding visionary leaders who are frustrated with the status quo and willing to take risks on new technology, rather than typical company people who follow standard processes.
vocabulary_highlights: tired of the status quo, leapfrog the world, stay on the escalator

speaker: Geoffrey Moore
text: All you really care about is cashflow positive. I just want to be able to keep doing what I'm doing. So you don't care about the actual GAAP accounting at all.
text_ko: 정말 신경 쓰는 건 현금 흐름이 흑자라는 것(cashflow positive)뿐이에요. 그냥 지금 하던 걸 계속할 수 있으면 돼요. 그러니까 실제 GAAP 회계(GAAP accounting)에는 전혀 신경 안 써요.
text_zh: 你真正在乎的就是现金流为正。我只是想能继续做我现在做的事儿。所以你根本不care那些GAAP会计准则(GAAP accounting)。
text_es: Lo único que realmente te importa es tener flujo de caja positivo. Yo solo quiero poder seguir haciendo lo que estoy haciendo. O sea que no te importa para nada la contabilidad GAAP real.
context: Lenny asks about Geoffrey's insight that you know you've crossed the chasm when you can survive without more venture funding, specifically wondering about the profit element. Geoffrey clarifies that crossing the chasm is about achieving operational sustainability rather than formal profitability. The goal is to reach a point where the company can continue operating and growing without requiring additional external funding, focusing on cash flow rather than accounting profits.
vocabulary_highlights: cashflow positive, GAAP accounting
topics: Starting a Company, Fundraising, Strategy & Planning

speaker: Geoffrey Moore
text: In the bowling alley, it's never about you. And that is so hard for a series of entrepreneurs because they want to give a demo, they want to tell the story, they want to share their vision. The answer is, "We don't care. We don't want to hear your story. We hate demos, and I don't know who you are and I don't care. I'm in trouble. We need to talk about me. We don't want to talk about you."
text_ko: 볼링장에서는 절대 당신에 대한 것이 아니에요. 이게 많은 기업가들에게 정말 힘든 부분인데, 그들은 데모를 보여주고 싶어하고, 이야기를 나누고 싶어하고, 자신의 비전을 공유하고 싶어하거든요. 하지만 대답은 이거예요, "우리는 관심 없어요. 당신의 이야기를 듣고 싶지 않아요. 데모도 싫고, 당신이 누구인지도 모르겠고, 관심도 없어요. 지금 나는 어려운 상황이에요. 우리는 나에 대해 이야기해야 해요. 당신에 대해 이야기하고 싶지 않아요."
text_zh: 在保龄球馆里，永远不是以你为中心的。这对很多创业者来说特别难接受，因为他们就想做产品演示(demo)，想讲自己的故事，想分享自己的愿景。但现实是："我们不在乎这些。我们不想听你的故事。我们讨厌看演示，我也不知道你是谁，也不关心。我现在有麻烦，咱们得聊聊我的问题。我们不想聊你的事儿。"
text_es: Mira, en el mundo de las ventas, nunca se trata de ti. Y esto les cuesta horrores a muchos emprendedores porque quieren hacer su presentación, quieren contar su historia, quieren compartir su visión. Pero la realidad es: "Nos da igual. No queremos escuchar tu rollo. Odiamos las demos, no sé quién eres y me importa un bledo. Yo tengo problemas. Necesitamos hablar de mí. No queremos hablar de ti."
context: Lenny clarifies that compelling reason to buy refers to the customer's pain point, not the company's sales pitch. Geoffrey explains the fundamental shift in sales approach needed for the bowling alley phase (crossing the chasm). He emphasizes that pragmatic customers experiencing serious business problems don't want product demos or company vision - they want solutions to their specific challenges and need consultative conversations focused on their situation.
vocabulary_highlights: bowling alley, series of entrepreneurs, I'm in trouble
topics: Communication Skills, Product Management, Growth & Marketing

speaker: Gergely Orosz
speaker_expertise: Software Engineering, Newsletter Creation, Community Building
text: In my best year at Uber, I made about 320 or $330,000 in total compensation. And when I quit my job, I was actually thinking, am I crazy? Because I am leaving... Especially in Europe, this is a lot of money. But now I am making more in compensation that I made at Uber. And the difference is that now my compensation... Well, my earnings keep going up as long as the newsletter is growing, so there's no theoretical cap on this.
text_ko: 우버에서 가장 잘 벌었던 해에 총보수(total compensation)가 대략 32만~33만 달러였어요. 회사를 그만둘 때는 솔직히 '내가 미친 건가?'라는 생각도 했어요. 떠나는 거였으니까요... 특히 유럽에선 정말 큰돈이잖아요. 그런데 지금은 우버 때보다 보수(compensation)를 더 받고 있어요. 차이라면 지금 제 수입은 뉴스레터(newsletter)가 성장하는 한 계속 늘어나서 이론적으로 상한선이 없다는 점이에요.
text_zh: 我在Uber最好的那年，总收入大概是32万到33万美金。当时辞职的时候，我真的在想，我是不是疯了？因为我要放弃这份工作...特别是在欧洲，这可是一大笔钱啊。但是现在我的收入已经超过了在Uber的时候。区别就在于，现在我的收入...怎么说呢，只要我的邮件订阅(newsletter)一直在增长，我的收入就会一直涨，理论上没有天花板。
text_es: En mi mejor año en Uber, gané como 320 o 330 mil dólares en compensación total. Y cuando renuncié, de verdad pensé: ¿estaré loco? Porque estaba dejando... Sobre todo en Europa, esa es muchísima plata. Pero ahora estoy ganando más de lo que ganaba en Uber. Y la diferencia es que ahora mi compensación... Bueno, mis ingresos siguen subiendo mientras el newsletter siga creciendo, así que no hay un tope teórico en esto.
context: Lenny asks Gergely to compare his income from running a paid newsletter versus his previous high-paying tech job at Uber. Gergely explains that he left a very lucrative position in Europe (around $330,000 annually) to pursue newsletter writing full-time, initially expecting to make much less money. He shares how his current newsletter income has surprisingly exceeded his Uber compensation, with the key difference being that newsletter earnings can theoretically grow indefinitely as long as subscriber numbers increase, unlike fixed corporate salaries.
vocabulary_highlights: theoretical cap, total compensation

speaker: Gergely Orosz
speaker_expertise: Software Engineering, Newsletter Creation, Community Building
text: So I was working on parallel things at the same time, and I was often running against the deadline, I was barely finishing it, which is not what I was expecting initially. The first few months I feel was a bit more stressed, but again, the good thing is I cleared my calendar, so I said I'm not talking with anyone, I'm just doing this.
text_ko: 그래서 저는 여러 일을 동시에 병행하고 있었고, 마감(deadline)에 자주 쫓겨 거의 간신히 마무리하곤 했어요. 처음에는 그렇게 될 줄 몰랐어요. 첫 몇 달은 스트레스를 좀 많이 받았던 것 같아요. 그래도 다행인 건 일정을 비워둬서 누구랑도 얘기하지 않고 이 일에만 집중하기로 했다는 점이에요.
text_zh: 所以我当时同时在做好几个项目，经常赶deadline，基本上都是卡着点儿完成，这跟我最初的预期完全不一样。头几个月压力确实挺大的，不过好在我把日程全清空了，跟谁都不见，就专心做这一件事。
text_es: Entonces estaba trabajando en varias cosas a la vez, y siempre andaba corriendo contra el tiempo, apenas lograba terminar, lo cual no era para nada lo que esperaba al principio. Los primeros meses sí me sentí bastante estresado, pero bueno, lo bueno es que liberé mi agenda completamente, o sea dije "no voy a hablar con nadie, solo me voy a enfocar en esto."
context: Lenny asks about what daily life is like running a newsletter full-time, since people might think writing one post per week sounds easy. Gergely explains that creating quality newsletter content actually takes much more time than expected - requiring research, writing, feedback, and editing phases that can span an entire week. He describes how the first few months were surprisingly stressful as he learned to manage multiple projects simultaneously while working against weekly publishing deadlines.
vocabulary_highlights: running against the deadline, barely finishing it, cleared my calendar

speaker: Gergely Orosz
speaker_expertise: Software Engineering, Newsletter Creation, Community Building
text: Without that, when you're on your own, when you're entrepreneur, I was a great... I think I was a really diligent employee. I always tried to get my work done, show up on time, I tried to meet all expectations. But what I noticed is, when I started to work for myself, it just went out the window. Almost 15 years of being this star employee who really wants to do well, I found myself upset at myself for not... Just wasting my day.
text_ko: 그게 없으니까, 혼자일 때나 창업가로 일할 때는요... 저는 정말 성실한 직원이었어요. 항상 일을 끝내려고 했고, 제시간에 출근했고, 모든 기대를 맞추려고 노력했어요. 그런데 혼자 일하기 시작하니까 그런 것들이 싹 사라지더라고요. 거의 15년 동안 잘하려고 애쓴 모범 직원이었는데, 막상 혼자 일하니까 하루를 그냥 낭비하는 제 자신에게 화가 났어요.
text_zh: 没有这个的话，当你自己创业的时候，我以前是个很棒的...我觉得我真的是个特别勤奋的员工。我总是努力把工作做完，按时上班，尽量达到所有要求。但我发现，当我开始为自己工作的时候，这些习惯就全没了。做了将近15年的明星员工，真的很想把事情做好，结果我发现自己在为没有...就是在浪费时间而生自己的气。
text_es: Sin eso, cuando trabajas por tu cuenta, cuando eres emprendedor... yo era un... creo que era un empleado muy responsable. Siempre trataba de terminar mi trabajo, llegar puntual, cumplir con todas las expectativas. Pero lo que me di cuenta es que cuando empecé a trabajar para mí mismo, se me fue todo por la borda. Casi 15 años de ser ese empleado estrella que de verdad quería destacar, y me encontré molesto conmigo mismo por no... simplemente por desperdiciar el día.
context: Gergely and Lenny are discussing the challenges of self-directed work and staying productive without external structure. Gergely shares a surprising discovery about the transition from corporate employment to entrepreneurship - despite being an extremely disciplined and high-performing employee for 15 years, he found himself struggling with productivity and time management when working independently. This illustrates a common challenge entrepreneurs face when they lose the external accountability and structure that corporate environments provide.
vocabulary_highlights: went out the window, diligent employee, star employee, wasting my day
topics: Starting a Company, Work-Life Balance, Learning & Growth

speaker: Gergely Orosz
speaker_expertise: Software Engineering, Newsletter Creation, Community Building
text: I use Twitter for a lot of research. And unfortunately what that means is when I start to write something, it can really pull my attention, because I have Twitter open and then I get a message from someone. It's a little bit like Slack, but I'd argue it can be worse, because also Twitter for me is also something that is very useful in generating people raising awareness.
text_ko: 저는 트위터(Twitter)를 리서치할 때 많이 사용해요. 안타깝게도 그게 의미하는 건, 뭔가 글을 쓰기 시작하면 트위터를 켜둔 상태에서 누가 메시지를 보내면 금방 집중이 흐트러진다는 거예요. 약간 슬랙(Slack) 같기도 한데, 오히려 더 나쁠 수 있어요. 제게 트위터는 사람들의 관심을 환기시키고 인식을 높이는 데도 정말 유용하거든요.
text_zh: 我经常用推特做研究。但问题是，一旦我开始写东西的时候，注意力就特别容易被分散，因为推特一直开着，然后就有人给我发消息。这跟Slack有点像，但我觉得推特可能更糟糕，因为对我来说，推特还有个很重要的作用就是帮我提升知名度、扩大影响力。
text_es: Uso Twitter para hacer mucha investigación. Y desafortunadamente lo que pasa es que cuando me pongo a escribir algo, me distrae muchísimo, porque tengo Twitter abierto y de repente me llega un mensaje de alguien. Es un poco como Slack, pero yo diría que puede ser peor, porque además Twitter para mí también es muy útil para generar que la gente se entere de las cosas, para crear awareness.
context: Lenny asks Gergely about productivity challenges and how to stay focused while working independently. Gergely describes a specific dilemma many content creators face - Twitter serves a dual purpose as both a research tool and a marketing platform for his newsletter business, making it difficult to avoid distractions. Unlike typical workplace distractions, social media platforms create a complex situation where the distraction source is also legitimately part of the work, making it harder to simply block or avoid.
vocabulary_highlights: pull my attention, raising awareness

speaker: Gergely Orosz
speaker_expertise: Software Engineering, Newsletter Creation, Community Building
text: And I was asking myself, all right, and then what? And I was like, after I've bought everything that I don't need, I probably want to share what I know with people, do YouTube videos and write books. And I was thinking to myself, so hold on. I would go off and do this for like ten years, because that's how much you need to plan to do it.
text_ko: 그래서 저는 '좋아, 그다음엔?' 하고 제 자신에게 물었어요. 그리고 '필요 없는 걸 다 사고 나면 아마 아는 걸 사람들과 나누고, 유튜브 영상도 만들고 책도 쓰게 될 거예요'라고 생각했어요. 그러다가 '잠깐만, 이걸 하려면 한 10년은 해야겠더라고요' 하고 생각했어요. 그만큼 장기적으로 계획해야 하니까요.
text_zh: 然后我就在想，好吧，接下来呢？我想着，等我把那些用不着的东西都买完了，我可能就想跟大家分享一下我知道的东西，做做YouTube视频，写写书什么的。然后我又想，等等，这样的话我得花个十年时间去搞这个，因为你得提前规划这么长时间才行。
text_es: Y me estaba preguntando, bueno, ¿y después qué? Y pensé, después de comprarme todo lo que no necesito, probablemente voy a querer compartir lo que sé con la gente, hacer videos de YouTube y escribir libros. Y me dije, espera un momento. Me iría a hacer esto como por diez años, porque eso es lo que necesitas planificar para hacerlo bien.
context: Gergely explains his thought process when deciding between starting a traditional venture-funded startup versus pursuing newsletter writing. He was calculating the potential financial outcomes of building a unicorn startup, realizing that even after achieving massive success (like a billion-dollar valuation), his ultimate goal would be to share knowledge through content creation - exactly what he could do immediately. This realization led him to question why he should spend a decade building a company just to end up doing what he was already interested in doing.
vocabulary_highlights: and then what?, go off and do this
topics: Starting a Company, Decision Making, Career Development

speaker: Gergely Orosz
speaker_expertise: Software Engineering, Newsletter Creation, Community Building
text: So there was years of work, and I wish I could tell you how to build a successful newsletter, but the best advice I have is still what Jeff Atwood does, except I have less conviction. But if you start writing, and you do it regularly, two things will happen. First of all, you're going to you write for yourself and you keep improving, you'll be a better writer. That's for sure.
text_ko: 그건 수년간의 작업이었어요. 성공적인 뉴스레터(newsletter)를 어떻게 만드는지 확실히 알려드리고 싶지만, 제가 드릴 수 있는 가장 좋은 조언은 제프 앳우드(Jeff Atwood)가 하는 방식이에요. 다만 저는 그만큼 확신은 없어요. 그래도 글쓰기를 시작해서 꾸준히 하면 두 가지가 일어나요. 우선 스스로를 위해 글을 쓰게 되고, 계속해서 실력이 늘면서 확실히 더 나은 글쓴이가 돼요.
text_zh: 所以这是好几年的功夫，我真希望能告诉你怎么做出一个成功的newsletter，但我能给的最好建议还是学Jeff Atwood那套，只不过我没他那么有把握。不过如果你开始写，而且坚持定期写的话，会有两个效果。首先，你为自己而写，不断改进，你的文笔肯定会越来越好。这个是肯定的。
text_es: Fueron años de trabajo, y me encantaría poder decirte cómo crear un newsletter exitoso, pero el mejor consejo que tengo sigue siendo lo que hace Jeff Atwood, aunque yo lo tengo menos claro. Pero si empiezas a escribir y lo haces con regularidad, van a pasar dos cosas. Primero, vas a escribir para ti mismo y vas a ir mejorando, vas a ser mejor escritor. Eso te lo aseguro.
context: Lenny asks how Gergely got his first thousand newsletter subscribers, expecting tactical advice. Gergely explains that his 'overnight success' was actually built on six years of consistent blogging and building an audience. He references advice from Jeff Atwood (Stack Overflow founder) about becoming internet-famous through consistent writing - publish regularly for an extended period. Gergely emphasizes that while he can't guarantee newsletter success, consistent writing practice will definitely improve your skills as a writer.
vocabulary_highlights: I have less conviction
topics: Learning & Growth, Starting a Company, Communication Skills

speaker: Georgiana Laudi
speaker_expertise: Growth Strategy, Marketing Strategy, Customer Journey Mapping
text: The problem with funnels and pirate metrics and the favorites that I love to pick on are MQLs and SQLs is that nobody knows what those mean. It puts every customer in the same sort of buckets. It assumes that all customers and all products are the same. It puts businesses, or they, I should say, puts businesses at the center of the business versus putting customers at the center.
text_ko: 퍼널(funnels)이나 파이럿 메트릭스(pirate metrics), 제가 자주 지적하는 MQLs(마케팅 적격 리드)와 SQLs(영업 적격 리드)의 문제는 아무도 그게 정확히 무엇을 뜻하는지 모른다는 거예요. 그런 접근법은 모든 고객을 똑같은 몇 개의 '버킷'에 넣어버리고, 모든 고객과 모든 제품이 같다고 가정하게 만들어요. 결과적으로 기업(비즈니스)을 중심에 놓고 고객을 중심에 두지 않게 되죠.
text_zh: 漏斗模型和海盗指标(pirate metrics)这些东西的问题，还有我最爱吐槽的MQL和SQL，就是根本没人搞得清楚这些到底是什么意思。这套方法把所有客户都往同一个框里装，默认所有客户、所有产品都一个样。结果呢，企业就以自己为中心在做生意，而不是以客户为中心。
text_es: El problema con los embudos y las métricas pirata y mis favoritos que me encanta criticar, que son los MQLs y SQLs, es que nadie sabe realmente qué significan. Meten a todos los clientes en las mismas cajitas. Asumen que todos los clientes y todos los productos son iguales. Ponen a las empresas, o mejor dicho, hacen que las empresas se pongan en el centro del negocio en lugar de poner a los clientes en el centro.
context: Lenny asks Georgiana why she calls her consultancy 'Forget The Funnel.' Georgiana explains her fundamental criticism of traditional marketing funnels and metrics like MQLs (Marketing Qualified Leads) and SQLs (Sales Qualified Leads). She argues these frameworks are outdated because they treat all customers the same way and focus on what's valuable to the business rather than what's valuable to customers.
vocabulary_highlights: love to pick on, sort of buckets, puts businesses at the center

speaker: Georgiana Laudi
speaker_expertise: Growth Strategy, Marketing Strategy, Customer Journey Mapping
text: Generally, the lowest hanging fruit outcome is realigning around better positioning and messaging. And identifying more resonant positioning and messaging that speaks to that context that I was talking about before, before people discover that you even exist, have that moment where they're like, "Oh my god, this has to change. This sucks," ties that in, ties in what they care about and what is valuable about your product and then also that desired outcome.
text_ko: 일반적으로 가장 쉬운 성과는 포지셔닝(positioning)과 메시징(messaging)을 더 잘 맞추는 거예요. 그리고 사람들이 당신을 알기도 전에—제가 아까 말한 그 맥락에서—'세상에, 이건 바뀌어야 해. 진짜 불편해'라고 느끼게 하는 더 공감되는 포지셔닝과 메시징을 찾아내는 거예요. 그걸 그 순간에 연결해서, 그들이 신경 쓰는 것과 제품의 가치, 그리고 그들이 원하는 결과(desired outcome)까지 엮어주는 거죠.
text_zh: 一般来说，最容易拿到的成果就是重新调整定位和信息传达。找到更有共鸣的定位和信息，能够切中我之前说的那个场景——就是在用户发现你之前，让他们产生那种"天哪，这个必须得改，太糟糕了"的想法，然后把这个跟他们真正关心的东西、你产品的价值点，还有他们想要达到的结果都串联起来。
text_es: Por lo general, lo más fácil de conseguir es reajustar el posicionamiento y la comunicación para que funcionen mejor. Se trata de encontrar un posicionamiento y mensajes que realmente conecten con ese contexto del que hablaba antes - antes de que la gente siquiera sepa que existes, captar ese momento cuando piensan "Dios mío, esto tiene que cambiar, esto es un desastre", y conectar eso con lo que realmente les importa, lo que tiene valor de tu producto, y también con el resultado que buscan.
context: Lenny asks about the impact Georgiana has seen working with companies through her process. Georgiana explains that the most immediate and common win from her customer research work is improving a company's positioning and messaging. She emphasizes the importance of connecting with customers' pre-discovery context - understanding their frustrations and problems before they even know your product exists.
vocabulary_highlights: lowest hanging fruit, more resonant, ties that in

speaker: Georgiana Laudi
speaker_expertise: Growth Strategy, Marketing Strategy, Customer Journey Mapping
text: So we end up seeing a messy middle there because there's no natural handoff. So pretty well, every company that we've worked with has had an opportunity to improve, especially product onboarding and product activation.
text_ko: 그래서 자연스러운 핸드오프(handoff)가 없으면 중간 부분이 뒤엉켜 보이게 돼요. 우리가 함께 일해 본 거의 모든 회사는 개선할 여지가 있었고, 특히 제품 온보딩(product onboarding)과 제품 활성화(product activation) 쪽에서요.
text_zh: 所以我们看到中间这一段就比较乱，因为没有一个自然的交接过程。基本上我们合作过的每家公司都有提升空间，特别是在产品引导(product onboarding)和产品激活(product activation)这块。
text_es: Entonces terminamos viendo un lío en el medio porque no hay una transición natural. Así que prácticamente todas las empresas con las que hemos trabajado han tenido oportunidad de mejorar, especialmente en la incorporación de usuarios (product onboarding) y la activación del producto (product activation).
context: Georgiana discusses why product onboarding is often neglected at companies. She explains that it falls into a gray area where it's unclear whether marketing or product teams should own it, especially for freemium products. This lack of clear ownership creates what she calls a 'messy middle' where the customer experience suffers, but also represents a major opportunity for improvement.
vocabulary_highlights: messy middle, natural handoff, pretty well

speaker: Georgiana Laudi
speaker_expertise: Growth Strategy, Marketing Strategy, Customer Journey Mapping
text: So what we did was, we identified SparkToro's best customers. Now, what I mean by best customers is those that get a ton of value from your product as of exist today, pay obviously. They're happy. They're low maintenance. And very importantly, they signed up for your product recently enough that they remember what life was like before.
text_ko: 그래서 저희가 한 건 SparkToro의 이상적인 고객을 찾아낸 거예요. 여기서 말하는 이상적인 고객이란, 지금 있는 제품에서 큰 가치를 얻고 있고(당연히 비용을 내요), 만족도가 높아서 손이 많이 가지 않으며, 무엇보다도 비교적 최근에 가입해서 제품 사용 전의 불편함을 아직 기억하는 고객들이에요.
text_zh: 所以我们当时做的就是，找出了SparkToro最优质的那些客户。我说的最优质客户是什么意思呢，就是那些从你现有产品中获得巨大价值的，当然了，付费也很爽快的。他们很满意，也不怎么折腾你。还有很重要的一点，他们注册使用你产品的时间还不算太久，所以还记得用你产品之前是什么样子的。
text_es: Entonces lo que hicimos fue identificar a los mejores clientes de SparkToro. Y cuando digo mejores clientes me refiero a aquellos que realmente sacan muchísimo provecho de tu producto tal como está ahora, que obviamente pagan. Están contentos. No dan lata. Y muy importante, se registraron hace poco tiempo, lo suficientemente reciente como para que todavía se acuerden de cómo era su vida antes.
context: Georgiana explains her methodology for customer research using SparkToro as an example. She defines 'best customers' not just as high-paying customers, but as those who get significant value, are satisfied, require minimal support, and crucially - signed up recently enough (3-6 months) to accurately remember their pre-product experience. This recency is key to getting reliable data about customer motivations.
vocabulary_highlights: get a ton of value, low maintenance

speaker: Georgiana Laudi
speaker_expertise: Growth Strategy, Marketing Strategy, Customer Journey Mapping
text: The whole pain killer versus vitamin thing, you always want to be selling a pain killer. So who has an urgent problem that needs solving, not something that they might have a problem with six months down the line?
text_ko: ‘페인킬러(pain killer)이냐 비타민(vitamin)이냐’ 하는 얘기에서는 항상 페인킬러를 팔아야 해요. 즉, 6개월 뒤에나 문제가 될 수도 있는 게 아니라 지금 당장 해결이 필요한 긴급한 문제가 있는 사람을 찾아야 해요.
text_zh: 止痛药和维生素的区别，你肯定要卖止痛药啊。就是说，谁现在就有急需解决的痛点，而不是那种可能六个月后才会遇到的问题，对吧？
text_es: Esa cosa del analgésico versus la vitamina, siempre hay que vender el analgésico. O sea, ¿quién tiene un problema urgente que necesita resolver ya mismo, y no algo con lo que tal vez tenga problemas dentro de seis meses?
context: Georgiana describes the criteria for prioritizing which customer segment to focus on when multiple options exist. She references the classic business concept of 'painkiller vs vitamin' - meaning you want to target customers who have an urgent, pressing problem that needs immediate solving, rather than a nice-to-have improvement they might consider in the future.
vocabulary_highlights: pain killer versus vitamin thing, six months down the line

speaker: Georgiana Laudi
speaker_expertise: Growth Strategy, Marketing Strategy, Customer Journey Mapping
text: We often talk about it and describe it as the story of how I met and fell in love with your product. It's like this documentary of being out in the world, finding it, realizing that like, "Hell yeah, this might actually solve a problem for us. This might be it." Getting that enough value to convince them to keep going to full value realization, to continue value-to-value growth.
text_ko: 우리는 이걸 종종 '여러분의 제품을 만나서 사랑에 빠진 이야기'라고 얘기해요. 세상 밖을 돌아다니다 우연히 그 제품을 발견하고, '와, 이거 진짜 우리 문제를 해결해줄 수도 있겠네. 이거다!' 하고 깨닫게 되는 다큐 같은 이야기예요. 사람들이 거기서 충분한 가치를 느껴서 계속 완전한 가치 실현(full value realization)까지 나아가고, 가치-대-가치 성장(value-to-value growth)을 이어가도록 설득하게 만드는 거예요.
text_zh: 我们经常说这就像是一个故事——我怎么遇到并且爱上了你们的产品。就好比拍纪录片一样，在外面转悠，突然发现了这个东西，然后意识到"哇塞，这玩意儿真的能帮我们解决问题啊，就是它了！"先让他们尝到甜头，觉得有价值，愿意继续用下去，最后实现产品的全部价值，形成价值增长的良性循环。
text_es: Siempre hablamos de esto y lo describimos como la historia de cómo conocí y me enamoré de tu producto. Es como un documental de estar ahí afuera en el mundo real, encontrarlo, y darte cuenta de que "¡Órale, esto sí podría resolver un problema para nosotros. Esto podría ser lo que buscamos." Conseguir el valor suficiente para convencerlos de seguir adelante hasta llegar a la realización completa del valor (full value realization), y continuar con ese crecimiento valor tras valor.
context: Georgiana explains how she conceptualizes customer journey mapping. Instead of traditional business funnels, she frames it as a love story or documentary that follows the customer's emotional journey from discovering a problem exists, through finding and evaluating the product, to getting value and growing their usage over time.
vocabulary_highlights: fell in love with, Hell yeah, This might be it, value-to-value growth

speaker: Georgiana Laudi
speaker_expertise: Growth Strategy, Marketing Strategy, Customer Journey Mapping
text: You want to reflect them back to them. That is what is going to show them that you understand the problem that they have and that your product has exactly what it is that they need.
text_ko: 그들이 말한 걸 그대로 되돌려줘야 해요. 그래야 그들이 가진 문제를 이해하고 있다는 걸 보여주고, 제품이 바로 그들이 필요로 하는 걸 정확히 갖추고 있다는 것도 알릴 수 있어요.
text_zh: 你要把他们的话反映回去给他们听。这样才能让他们知道你真的理解他们遇到的问题，而且你的产品正好能解决他们的需求。
text_es: Tienes que reflejarles sus propias palabras. Así es como les vas a demostrar que realmente entiendes su problema y que tu producto tiene exactamente lo que necesitan.
context: Lenny asks for messaging tips once you understand your customer journey. Georgiana emphasizes the importance of using customer research and voice-of-customer data to inform messaging. Her key insight is that effective messaging should mirror customers' own language back to them, demonstrating deep understanding of their problems and showing that your product provides the exact solution they need.
vocabulary_highlights: reflect them back to them

speaker: Gibson Biddle
speaker_expertise: Product Strategy, Product Management, B2B SaaS
text: The A/B test we set up, we said, okay, everybody says they want this, in focus groups and qualitative and surveys. Well, let's A/B test and see what we really learn. So, the AB test was called the Perfect New Release Test. Imagine we're at about a million customers circa 2005. 10,000 peeps are in a test cell. They get their new release DVD the next day in the mail. Awesome, right? And the control gets it whenever. Let's say, average maybe two weeks later.
text_ko: 우리가 세운 A/B 테스트(A/B test)는, 포커스 그룹(focus groups)이나 정성(qualitative) 인터뷰랑 설문(surveys)에서 다들 이걸 원한다고 하길래, '그럼 A/B 테스트로 실제로 뭘 배우는지 보자' 하고 한 거예요. 그래서 그 A/B 테스트는 퍼펙트 뉴 릴리스 테스트(Perfect New Release Test)라고 불렀어요. 2005년쯤 고객이 대략 백만 명 정도 있다고 가정해 보세요. 테스트 셀(test cell)에는 1만 명이 들어가고, 그분들은 신작 DVD를 다음 날 우편으로 받아요. 멋지죠? 반면 대조군(control)은 평소대로 받고, 평균적으로 아마 2주쯤 늦게 받는다고 합시다.
text_zh: 我们设置的A/B测试是这样的，我们说，好吧，所有人在焦点小组、定性研究和调研中都说他们想要这个功能。那我们就做个A/B测试，看看到底能学到什么。这个AB测试叫做"完美新片发布测试"。想象一下，2005年左右我们大概有一百万用户。一万个人在测试组里。他们第二天就能收到新上架的DVD邮件。很棒，对吧？而对照组呢，就是正常时间收到。比如说，平均可能要两周后才收到。
text_es: La prueba A/B que montamos, dijimos, bueno, todo el mundo dice que quiere esto en los focus groups y en las encuestas cualitativas. Pues hagamos una prueba A/B a ver qué aprendemos en realidad. Entonces, la prueba A/B se llamaba Perfect New Release Test. Imagínate que tenemos como un millón de clientes por el 2005. 10,000 personas están en el grupo de prueba. Les llega su DVD nuevo al día siguiente por correo. Genial, ¿no? Y el grupo de control lo recibe cuando sea. Digamos, en promedio como dos semanas después.
context: Lenny asks Gibson about how Netflix balanced delight versus margin when making product decisions. Gibson explains how Netflix tested customer requests for faster access to new DVD releases. The Perfect New Release Test was an A/B test where 10,000 customers received their new release DVDs the next day, while the control group waited the usual two weeks. This test was designed to validate whether what customers said they wanted in surveys and focus groups would actually impact their behavior and retention when delivered.
vocabulary_highlights: test cell, new release, control gets it whenever

speaker: Gibson Biddle
speaker_expertise: Product Strategy, Product Management, B2B SaaS
text: Amazon would use a 10X, right? And so, sort of a wash there. You'd probably lean forward and do it. We actually worked hard to try to isolate what that word of mouth factor was. It was really frustrating. And then, the reality was, Barry McCarthy was the CFO. He was apoplectic about the idea of using a 2X, because it means you'll invest more in building a better product.
text_ko: 아마존이라면 10배(10X)를 썼을 거예요, 그렇죠? 그래서 그 부분은 어느 정도 상쇄됐어요. 아마 당신은 좀 더 적극적으로 밀어붙였을 거예요. 사실 우리는 그 '입소문 효과(word-of-mouth factor)'가 정확히 뭔지 분리해서 규명하려고 정말 애썼어요. 정말 답답했어요. 그리고 실제로 배리 맥카시는 최고재무책임자(CFO)였는데, 그는 2배(2X)를 쓰자는 아이디어에 매우 분개했어요. 그건 더 나은 제품을 만들기 위해 더 많이 투자해야 한다는 뜻이니까요.
text_zh: 亚马逊肯定会用10倍系数，对吧？所以这样算下来基本持平。你可能还是会倾向于去做这件事。我们当时真的很努力想把口碑效应(word of mouth factor)这个因素单独分离出来，结果搞得特别头疼。然后现实情况是，Barry McCarthy是我们的CFO，一听到要用2倍系数他就炸毛了，因为这意味着你要在产品上砸更多钱。
text_es: Amazon usaría un 10X, ¿verdad? Entonces, digamos que ahí se equilibra la cosa. Probablemente te inclinarías por hacerlo. De hecho trabajamos duro para tratar de aislar ese factor de boca a boca (word of mouth). Era súper frustrante. Y entonces, la realidad era que Barry McCarthy era el CFO. Se puso como loco con la idea de usar un 2X, porque significa que vas a invertir más en crear un mejor producto.
context: Gibson is discussing Netflix's Perfect New Release Test results and how they calculated the business value of retaining customers. He explains that Netflix used a 2X word-of-mouth multiplier (assuming each happy customer would refer one additional customer), but notes that other companies like Amazon might use 10X multipliers. The CFO Barry McCarthy was strongly opposed to using higher multipliers because it would justify more expensive product investments that the company couldn't afford at the time.
vocabulary_highlights: lean forward and do it, isolate, apoplectic
topics: Product Management, Decision Making, Strategy & Planning

speaker: Gibson Biddle
speaker_expertise: Product Strategy, Product Management, B2B SaaS
text: As a rule, I never used rules as thumbs, but these two percenters, I would kill them. If I launched something and it was only 2% we'd, we called it scraping the barnacles, just get rid of it.
text_ko: 원칙적으로는 경험칙(rules of thumb)에 얽매이지 않아요. 하지만 이런 2%짜리(two percenters)에 대해서는 가차 없었어요. 뭔가 출시했는데 겨우 2%밖에 안 나왔다면, 우리는 그걸 '따개비 긁어내기(scraping the barnacles)'라고 부르곤 했고 그냥 없앴어요.
text_zh: 我有个原则，从来不把规则当作经验法则来用，但是那些只有2%的项目，我会直接砍掉。如果我们推出什么东西，结果只有2%的效果，我们就叫它"刮船底的藤壶"，直接扔掉算了。
text_es: Por regla general, nunca me guié por reglas fijas, pero con esos proyectos del 2%, los eliminaba sin piedad. Si lanzábamos algo y solo daba un 2%, lo llamábamos "raspar percebes" - simplemente nos deshacíamos de eso.
context: Lenny asks Gibson about Netflix's decision not to launch a Netflix Party feature for watching with friends. Gibson explains his philosophy about product features that only appeal to a small percentage of users. He describes "two percenters" as features used by only 2% of customers, which he would eliminate because they add complexity without meaningful impact. Netflix would remove these underperforming features in a process they called "scraping the barnacles."
vocabulary_highlights: two percenters, scraping the barnacles

speaker: Gibson Biddle
speaker_expertise: Product Strategy, Product Management, B2B SaaS
text: I was thinking about what's different. For instance, one of the hard to copy advantages of B2B is switching costs, right? I didn't bring that up in the context of Netflix. It's wicked hard to cancel. It's wicked easy to cancel Netflix and restart Disney+, whatever you want to do.
text_ko: 뭐가 다른지 생각해봤어요. 예를 들어, B2B에서 쉽게 따라할 수 없는 장점 중 하나가 전환 비용(switching costs)인데, 맞죠? 넷플릭스와 관련해서는 그걸 언급하지 않았어요. 넷플릭스는 해지하기가 진짜 어렵고, 반면에 넷플릭스를 취소하고 디즈니+를 다시 시작하는 건 정말 쉽잖아요. 원하는 대로 할 수 있으니까요.
text_zh: 我在想有什么不同的地方。比如说，B2B一个很难被复制的优势就是转换成本(switching costs)，对吧？我刚才说Netflix的时候没提到这一点。Netflix真的是太容易取消了。你想取消Netflix然后开通Disney+什么的，那都是分分钟的事。
text_es: Estaba pensando en qué es lo que marca la diferencia. Por ejemplo, una de las ventajas difíciles de copiar en B2B son los costos de cambio (switching costs), ¿no? No mencioné eso cuando hablamos de Netflix. Es súper difícil cancelar. Con Netflix es facilísimo cancelar y empezar con Disney+, o lo que sea que quieras hacer.
context: Lenny asks Gibson whether his "delight customers in hard-to-copy, margin-enhancing ways" framework applies to B2B products. Gibson explains key differences between B2B and consumer products, noting that B2B companies often rely on switching costs as a competitive advantage - it's difficult and expensive for businesses to change software providers. He contrasts this with Netflix, where customers can easily cancel and switch to competitors like Disney+ without significant friction or cost.
vocabulary_highlights: switching costs, wicked hard, wicked easy

speaker: Gibson Biddle
speaker_expertise: Product Strategy, Product Management, B2B SaaS
text: So, at any moment in time... You actually had one of my board members on a podcast, Melissa Perri. She's on my board, right? Yeah, you voted for her. So, short answer is, it's really easy to build your community of peers. Just keep up your former colleagues. Keep up on LinkedIn. The harder part is building the mentors.
text_ko: 그러니까, 사실 얼마 전에도 당신이 제 이사회 멤버 중 한 분인 멜리사 페리(Melissa Perri)님을 팟캐스트(podcast)에 초대하셨잖아요. 그분 제 이사회에 계시고요, 맞아요, 당신이 투표하셨죠. 요약하자면 동료 커뮤니티는 만드는 게 정말 쉬워요. 예전 동료들과 관계만 계속 유지하고 링크드인(LinkedIn)에서 소식만 주고받으면 돼요. 더 어려운 건 멘토를 만드는 거예요.
text_zh: 所以说，随时随地...你之前还采访过我的董事会成员呢，Melissa Perri。她在我董事会，对吧？是的，你投票支持过她。简单来说就是，建立同行圈子其实挺容易的，就是跟以前的同事保持联系，在LinkedIn上多互动。真正难的是找到导师。
text_es: Entonces, en cualquier momento... De hecho tuviste a una de las miembros de mi junta directiva en un podcast, Melissa Perri. Está en mi junta, ¿verdad? Sí, votaste por ella. Bueno, la respuesta corta es que es súper fácil construir tu comunidad de colegas. Solo mantente en contacto con tus antiguos compañeros. Mantente activo en LinkedIn. Lo más difícil es conseguir mentores.
context: Gibson is explaining his concept of building a "personal board of directors" - a network of peers and mentors who can provide advice and guidance throughout your career. He mentions that Melissa Perri, a product management expert who appeared on Lenny's podcast, is one of his board members. Gibson distinguishes between peers (easier to maintain through platforms like LinkedIn) and mentors (harder to cultivate), emphasizing that building relationships with former colleagues is a simple starting point for creating this advisory network.
vocabulary_highlights: board members, community of peers, keep up

speaker: Gibson Biddle
speaker_expertise: Product Strategy, Product Management, B2B SaaS
text: The hardest part in that model is, how do you balance delight versus margin? So if Netflix said, hey, everybody, you're paying $20 bucks a day, but you're going to get exactly the same service tomorrow for $5 bucks a month, you'd be just like, this is fricking awesome. You'd be delighted. But Netflix would not, the business wouldn't work.
text_ko: 그 모델(model)에서 가장 어려운 건 고객을 기쁘게 하는 정도(delight)와 마진(margin)을 어떻게 균형 잡느냐에요. 예를 들어 넷플릭스가 “여러분, 지금은 하루에 20달러 내고 계시죠? 근데 내일부터 똑같은 서비스를 월 5달러에 드릴게요”라고 하면 사람들은 “와, 진짜 대박이다” 하고 엄청 좋아하실 거예요. 하지만 넷플릭스 입장에서는 그렇게 하면 비즈니스가 성립하지 않아요.
text_zh: 这个模式最难的地方就是，你怎么在用户满意度和利润率之间找平衡？比如说Netflix突然告诉大家，你们现在一天交20美元，但从明天开始同样的服务只要一个月5美元，用户肯定会觉得太棒了，开心得不得了。但Netflix就惨了，这生意根本没法做下去。
text_es: Lo más difícil de ese modelo es, ¿cómo equilibras la satisfacción del cliente versus el margen de ganancia? O sea, si Netflix dijera, oye, todos están pagando 20 dólares al día, pero mañana van a recibir exactamente el mismo servicio por 5 dólares al mes, dirías, esto está padrísimo. Estarías encantado. Pero Netflix no, el negocio no funcionaría.
context: Gibson is explaining his product strategy framework of "delighting customers in hard-to-copy, margin-enhancing ways." He identifies the core challenge of this model: finding the right balance between customer delight and business profitability. Using a hypothetical example, he illustrates that while drastically reducing Netflix's price from $20 to $5 would absolutely delight customers, it would destroy the company's ability to generate revenue and maintain operations, demonstrating why pure customer delight without regard for business sustainability isn't viable.
vocabulary_highlights: fricking awesome

speaker: Gina Gotthilf
speaker_expertise: Growth Strategy, Marketing Strategy, Community Building
text: Communication is constantly underrated. And communication isn't about being able to convey a message, it's about being able to convey a message in a way that the listener receives it, and understands it, and remembers it. And that's really hard to do.
text_ko: 커뮤니케이션(communication)은 늘 과소평가돼요. 단순히 메시지를 전달할 수 있다는 게 중요한 게 아니라, 듣는 사람이 그걸 받아들이고 이해하고 기억하게끔 전달하는 방식이 진짜 중요한 거예요. 그걸 해내기는 정말 어려워요.
text_zh: 大家总是小看沟通的重要性。沟通不是说你能把话说出来就行了，关键是你得让听的人能接收到、听明白、还能记住，这才是真正的沟通。这个真的很难做到。
text_es: La comunicación siempre está súper subestimada. Y comunicar no se trata de poder transmitir un mensaje, sino de poder transmitirlo de tal manera que quien te escucha lo reciba, lo entienda y se acuerde de él. Y eso es realmente difícil de lograr.
context: Gina begins the podcast by sharing one of her key beliefs about effective communication. She's discussing how true communication goes far beyond simply delivering information - it requires ensuring the message is not only heard but actually absorbed and retained by the audience. This insight reflects her experience in growth marketing and brand building at companies like Duolingo.
vocabulary_highlights: constantly underrated, convey a message, really hard to do

speaker: Gina Gotthilf
speaker_expertise: Growth Strategy, Marketing Strategy, Community Building
text: One of the things I've helped employ at Duolingo that I think is still there today, it's definitely not just me, it was an amazing team, is a unique voice. And what that means is not just another language learning app where we give you instructions and you follow directions. There is always a quirk, like it's unexpected. The way we talk to you is a little bit funny. It doesn't take ourselves too seriously and it makes the person receiving this message feel something.
text_ko: 제가 Duolingo에서 도입하는 데 도움을 준 것 중 하나로, 지금도 남아 있다고 생각하는 게 있어요. 물론 저 혼자 한 건 아니고 훌륭한 팀이 있었어요. 그건 바로 '독특한 목소리'(unique voice)예요. 그게 무슨 뜻이냐면, 단순히 지시를 주고 그대로 따라 하게 하는 평범한 언어 학습 앱(language learning app)이 아니라는 거예요. 항상 어딘가에 약간의 기발한 요소(quirk)가 있어서 예상치 못한 면이 있고, 우리가 사용자에게 말하는 방식이 조금 웃기고 우리 자신을 너무 심각하게 여기지 않아요. 그래서 그 메시지를 받는 사람이 뭔가를 느끼게 해요.
text_zh: 我在多邻国(Duolingo)帮忙建立的一个东西，现在应该还在用，当然不是我一个人的功劳，是整个团队都很棒，就是打造了一个很独特的品牌调性。这个意思就是说，我们不想做成那种普通的语言学习应用，就是给你指令然后你照着做。我们总是会有点小怪癖，让人意想不到的那种。我们跟用户说话的方式会有点幽默感，不会太严肃，这样用户收到信息的时候就会有感觉，有共鸣。
text_es: Una de las cosas que ayudé a implementar en Duolingo y que creo que sigue ahí hoy en día, y por supuesto no fue solo yo sino un equipo increíble, es una voz única. Y lo que esto significa es que no somos simplemente otra app de idiomas donde te damos instrucciones y tú sigues las indicaciones. Siempre hay algo peculiar, algo inesperado. La forma en que te hablamos es un poco divertida. No nos tomamos demasiado en serio y eso hace que la persona que recibe este mensaje sienta algo.
context: Lenny asks about what made Duolingo successful as one of the rare consumer subscription apps that thrived. Gina explains how Duolingo differentiated itself from typical educational apps by developing a distinctive brand voice that was quirky, funny, and emotionally engaging rather than just instructional. She emphasizes that creating an emotional connection with users was crucial to the app's growth and retention.
vocabulary_highlights: helped employ, unique voice, there is always a quirk, doesn't take ourselves too seriously
topics: Growth & Marketing, Communication Skills, Product Management

speaker: Gina Gotthilf
speaker_expertise: Growth Strategy, Marketing Strategy, Community Building
text: We are very encouraged in our lives, especially professionally, to talk about our A-sides all the time.
