Because that's what impresses people, that's what opens doors, that's what allows us to keep growing and it's so important. It means that a lot of what you hear in podcasts and on stage ends up being the Instagramable version of someone, or a company, or a country's trajectory. It's just the highlights.
text_ko: 우리 삶, 특히 직업적으로는 항상 'A-사이드(A-sides)'만 얘기하라고 많이들 권장해요. 사람들이 감동받고 문을 열어주고 계속 성장하게 해주는 게 바로 그 부분이라 정말 중요한 건 맞거든요. 그래서 팟캐스트나 강연에서 듣는 이야기들 상당수가 개인이나 회사, 나아가 한 나라의 궤적까지도 인스타에 올리기 좋은(Instagramable) 버전으로 정리돼요. 결국은 하이라이트만 있는 거죠.
text_zh: 我们在生活中，特别是职场上，总是被鼓励要展示自己最好的一面。因为这样才能给人留下深刻印象，才能为我们打开机会的大门，才能让我们不断成长，这确实很重要。但这也意味着，你在播客里听到的，在台上看到的，往往都是经过包装的版本——不管是个人、公司还是国家的发展轨迹，基本上都只是那些亮点时刻。
text_es: Nos animan mucho en la vida, sobre todo en el ámbito profesional, a hablar siempre de nuestro lado bueno. Porque eso es lo que impresiona a la gente, lo que te abre puertas, lo que te permite seguir creciendo y es súper importante. Esto hace que mucho de lo que escuchas en podcasts y en conferencias termine siendo la versión "instagrameable" de alguien, de una empresa, o de la trayectoria de un país. Solo son los momentos estelares.
context: Lenny asks Gina to explain her concept of A-side and B-side, which she referenced from her conference talk. Gina uses the analogy of vinyl records having an A-side (the hit song) and B-side (the lesser-known track) to describe how people only share their successes publicly while hiding their struggles and failures. She argues that this creates an unrealistic 'Instagram-perfect' narrative that doesn't reflect the full reality of anyone's journey.
vocabulary_highlights: encouraged in our lives, opens doors, Instagramable version, it's just the highlights

speaker: Gina Gotthilf
speaker_expertise: Growth Strategy, Marketing Strategy, Community Building
text: My one learning there that has stuck with me, and I think can work for other people too, is that it's not just about doing things that actually matter, and learning. It's about being able to tell the story, and it's about understanding what other people perceive as valuable.
text_ko: 거기서 제가 얻은 한 가지 교훈은 아직도 제게 남아 있고, 다른 사람들에게도 통할 수 있다고 생각해요. 중요한 일을 하고 배우는 것만으로는 충분하지 않고, 그걸 잘 설명할 수 있는 스토리텔링(storytelling) 능력과 다른 사람들이 무엇을 가치 있게 여기는지 이해하는 게 더 중요하다는 거예요.
text_zh: 我在那儿学到的一个道理，到现在还印象特别深，我觉得对其他人也有用，就是说光做有意义的事情、光学习是不够的。你得会讲故事，得明白别人眼里什么才是有价值的。
text_es: Mi gran aprendizaje de esa época, que se me ha quedado grabado y creo que le puede servir a otros también, es que no se trata solo de hacer cosas que realmente importen y de aprender. Se trata de saber contar la historia, y de entender qué es lo que los demás ven como valioso.
context: Lenny asks Gina to share a B-side story from her life. Gina recounts her early struggles, including dropping out of college due to depression, having a college counselor tell her she had 'nothing to show for' her time, and facing multiple job rejections and layoffs. From these experiences, she learned an important lesson about the psychology of career advancement and how perception matters as much as actual accomplishments.
vocabulary_highlights: has stuck with me, tell the story, perceive as valuable

speaker: Gina Gotthilf
speaker_expertise: Growth Strategy, Marketing Strategy, Community Building
text: So we deployed historic amounts of money in the campaign. It wasn't me, Gina, personally. I think that's important to share. So my Bloomberg presidential campaign was spending roughly a million dollars a day. Which is crazy. And you can do a lot with a million dollars a day.
text_ko: 그래서 우리는 캠페인에 역대급 규모의 돈을 쏟아부었어요. 그건 저나 지나가 개인적으로 한 건 아니었어요. 이건 꼭 공유해야 할 것 같아요. 블룸버그 대선 캠페인(Bloomberg presidential campaign)은 하루에 대략 백만 달러를 썼어요. 정말 미친 수준이에요. 하루에 백만 달러면 할 수 있는 일이 엄청 많아요.
text_zh: 所以我们在竞选活动中投入了史无前例的资金。我要澄清一下，这不是我吉娜个人出的钱，我觉得这点很重要。当时我的彭博总统竞选团队每天大概要烧掉一百万美金。这简直太疯狂了。你想想，一天一百万美金能干多少事儿啊。
text_es: Entonces desplegamos cantidades históricas de dinero en la campaña. No fui yo, Gina, personalmente. Creo que es importante aclarar eso. Mi campaña presidencial de Bloomberg estaba gastando aproximadamente un millón de dólares al día. Lo cual es una locura. Y puedes hacer muchísimo con un millón de dólares diarios.
context: Lenny asks Gina about her experience working on Mike Bloomberg's presidential campaign, specifically about deploying a historic amount of money on paid advertising. Gina clarifies that while the campaign as a whole spent massive amounts (around $1 million per day), she personally wasn't responsible for that entire budget. She's setting up to share lessons learned from working with such unprecedented advertising spend.
vocabulary_highlights: deployed historic amounts, roughly a million dollars a day

speaker: Gina Gotthilf
speaker_expertise: Growth Strategy, Marketing Strategy, Community Building
text: Which is, once you click on an ad, you land somewhere. And then whatever happens there is super important. Because if people then take the action you want them to take on that landing page, or don't, is definitive. But everyone spends all of their effort and money on the ads.
text_ko: 광고(ad)를 클릭하면 어딘가로 이동하게 되죠. 그곳에서 무슨 일이 일어나는지가 정말 중요해요. 랜딩 페이지(landing page)에서 사람들이 우리가 원하는 행동을 하느냐 안 하느냐가 결국 결정적이에요. 그런데 다들 모든 노력과 돈을 광고에만 쏟아부어요.
text_zh: 就是说，用户点了广告之后，会跳转到一个页面。然后在那个页面上发生的事情特别关键。因为用户在那个落地页(landing page)上到底会不会按你希望的去做，这就是成败的关键。但是大家都把精力和钱全砸在广告上了。
text_es: O sea, una vez que haces clic en un anuncio, llegas a algún lugar. Y lo que pasa ahí es súper importante. Porque si la gente hace lo que tú quieres que haga en esa página de aterrizaje (landing page), o no lo hace, eso es lo que define todo. Pero todo el mundo se gasta todo su esfuerzo y dinero en los anuncios.
context: Gina is explaining what she learned from working on the Bloomberg campaign with their massive advertising budget. She describes how there were many talented people focused on creating and optimizing ads, but she realized that most people overlook what happens after someone clicks an ad - the landing page experience. She decided to focus her efforts on optimizing landing pages rather than competing with others on ad creation, which proved highly effective.
vocabulary_highlights: land somewhere, is definitive, all of their effort

speaker: Gina Gotthilf
speaker_expertise: Growth Strategy, Marketing Strategy, Community Building
text: Very few people really believed that we were going to make it, not surprisingly. Even though we had this amazing team, et cetera, now it looks almost obvious, it's like B to C language learning just seems so niche. And plus education, there's no money in education. It's been stuck for so long.
text_ko: 솔직히 우리가 해낼 거라고 진짜 믿은 사람은 거의 없었어요. 그럴 만했죠. 멋진 팀도 있고 여러 조건이 있었음에도, 지금 보면 다 당연해 보이거든요. B to C(B2C) 방식의 언어 학습은 워낙 틈새처럼 보였고, 게다가 교육은 돈이 안 된다는 인식이 강했어요. 교육 분야는 오랫동안 정체돼 있기도 했고요.
text_zh: 当时真正相信我们能成功的人寥寥无几，这也不奇怪。虽然我们有这个超棒的团队什么的，现在回头看好像很显而易见，但当时B2C语言学习这块儿看起来就是个很小众的市场。再加上教育行业嘛，大家都觉得教育不赚钱，这个行业卡在那儿太久了。
text_es: Muy poca gente realmente creía que lo íbamos a lograr, lo cual no sorprende para nada. Aunque teníamos este equipo increíble y todo eso, ahora parece casi obvio, es como que el aprendizaje de idiomas B2C se ve súper nicho. Y además la educación, no hay plata en educación. Ha estado estancada por muchísimo tiempo.
context: Lenny asks Gina what Duolingo did right to become one of the rare successful consumer subscription businesses, noting that most B2C subscription apps fail. Gina explains that initially, few people believed Duolingo would succeed because language learning seemed like a niche market and education technology was seen as unprofitable. She's setting up to explain what factors actually made Duolingo successful despite these perceived limitations.
vocabulary_highlights: make it, seems so niche, no money in education, stuck for so long

speaker: Gokul Rajaram
speaker_expertise: Product Management, Company Building, Venture Capital
text: I think it's very important to do a core job really well at any company, but it's equally important to have curiosity and be open to serendipity. I think Zoom makes it harder, but it's very important to understand what else is going on at the company, what else people are working on, and just keep talking to people and build relationship with the company, because those are what will lead to the next set of opportunities.
text_ko: 어떤 회사에서든 핵심 업무를 정말 잘하는 건 굉장히 중요해요. 하지만 똑같이 중요한 건 호기심을 갖고 우연한 기회(serendipity)에 열려 있는 자세예요. Zoom 때문에 그런 게 더 어려워졌다고 생각하지만, 회사에서 무슨 일이 일어나고 있는지, 동료들이 어떤 걸 하고 있는지 파악하고 계속 사람들과 대화하면서 관계를 쌓아 가는 게 매우 중요해요. 그런 것들이 다음 기회로 이어지거든요.
text_zh: 我觉得在任何公司把核心工作做好都很重要，但同样重要的是要保持好奇心，对意外机会保持开放态度。我觉得Zoom让这变得更难了，但了解公司里还在发生什么事，别人在做什么项目，多跟人聊天，在公司里建立人脉关系，这些都非常重要，因为这些才会给你带来下一波机会。
text_es: Creo que es súper importante hacer muy bien tu trabajo principal en cualquier empresa, pero igual de importante es tener curiosidad y estar abierto a las oportunidades que surgen de casualidad. Creo que Zoom lo hace más difícil, pero es clave entender qué más está pasando en la empresa, en qué más está trabajando la gente, y simplemente seguir hablando con las personas y construir relaciones dentro de la compañía, porque eso es lo que te va a llevar al siguiente grupo de oportunidades.
context: Lenny asks Gokul about his journey to becoming a tech leader. Gokul shares how he discovered Google AdSense by walking around the office after hours and finding engineers working on a side project, eventually becoming their part-time PM. He explains that great career opportunities often don't come from linear progression but from staying curious about what's happening around you and building relationships across the company.
vocabulary_highlights: be open to serendipity, build relationship with the company, lead to the next set of opportunities

speaker: Gokul Rajaram
speaker_expertise: Product Management, Company Building, Venture Capital
text: I think many opportunities don't come linearly just working in your job and making sure you get promoted. That's not how I think great careers are built. I think great careers are built by knowing a lot of people doing great work so they know and want you on their teams, and just waiting for serendipity and then seizing it and jumping.
text_ko: 저는 많은 기회가 그냥 직장 생활만 하고 승진만 하면 알아서 오는 건 아니라고 생각해요. 그렇게 해서 훌륭한 커리어가 만들어지는 건 아니에요. 좋은 커리어는 훌륭한 일을 하는 사람들을 많이 알고 있어서 그 사람들이 당신을 알고 팀에 데려가고 싶어 하게 만드는 것, 그리고 우연한 기회(serendipity)를 기다렸다가 그 기회가 오면 과감히 잡고 뛰어드는 것으로 만들어진다고 봐요.
text_zh: 我觉得很多机会不是靠在一个岗位上埋头苦干、等着升职就能得到的。真正牛的职业发展不是这么来的。我认为要想事业做得好，就得认识很多厉害的人，自己活儿也得干得漂亮，这样他们才会想要你加入他们的团队。然后就是等机缘巧合，一旦碰上了就得抓住，该跳就跳。
text_es: Creo que muchas oportunidades no llegan de forma lineal solo trabajando en tu puesto y asegurándo que te asciendan. Así no es como se construyen las grandes carreras. Pienso que las grandes carreras se construyen conociendo a mucha gente, haciendo un trabajo excelente para que te conozcan y te quieran en sus equipos, y simplemente esperando a que llegue la casualidad afortunada (serendipity) para entonces aprovecharla y lanzarte.
context: Gokul continues explaining his career philosophy after sharing how random encounters led to major opportunities like joining Square. He argues against the traditional approach of focusing solely on your current role to get promoted, instead advocating for building a broad network within your company and being ready to act when unexpected opportunities arise.
vocabulary_highlights: don't come linearly, seizing it and jumping

speaker: Gokul Rajaram
speaker_expertise: Product Management, Company Building, Venture Capital
text: I think the biggest one is, the founder becomes too tactical and disempowers their team. I think the founder thinks they know what customers want. I think they don't empower their teams enough and they basically just tell the engineers what to build. And I think that leads to teams that are basically tactically just shaping feature after feature without truly solving problems.
text_ko: 제가 보기엔 제일 큰 문제는 창업자(founder)가 너무 전술적(tactical)으로 변해서 팀의 자율성을 빼앗는다는 점이에요. 창업자는 자기가 고객이 뭘 원하는지 안다고 생각하고, 팀에 충분히 권한을 주지 않은 채 그냥 엔지니어(engineers)들에게 무엇을 만들어야 할지 지시해요. 그러다 보니 팀은 근본적인 문제를 해결하기보다 전술적으로 기능(feature)들만 잇달아 만드는 수준에 그치게 돼요.
text_zh: 我觉得最大的问题就是，创始人管得太细了，把团队的权力都收走了。创始人总觉得自己最懂客户要什么，不给团队足够的自主权，基本上就是直接告诉工程师该做什么。这样搞下去，团队就变成纯执行的了，一个功能接一个功能地堆，根本解决不了真正的问题。
text_es: Creo que el problema más grande es que el fundador se vuelve demasiado operativo y le quita poder a su equipo. El fundador piensa que sabe lo que quieren los clientes. No empodera lo suficiente a sus equipos y básicamente solo les dice a los ingenieros qué construir. Y eso lleva a equipos que están solo desarrollando funcionalidad tras funcionalidad de manera táctica, sin realmente resolver problemas de fondo.
context: Lenny asks about common pitfalls in startup product development processes. Gokul identifies the biggest mistake as founders who micromanage by dictating specific features rather than presenting problems for their teams to solve. This creates what he calls a 'feature factory' where teams build features without understanding their impact on customer behavior.
vocabulary_highlights: becomes too tactical, disempowers their team, shaping feature after feature

speaker: Gokul Rajaram
speaker_expertise: Product Management, Company Building, Venture Capital
text: Engineers are by far the most expensive resources in the company. By far, right? I mean if you look at the composition of engineers versus... And PMs versus any other function, it's two to three, equity, cash, everything. And if you think of it that way, then if you're not caring and feeding and not leveraging this amazing most expensive resource, well, that's a crime.
text_ko: 엔지니어(engineers)는 회사에서 단연 가장 비싼 자원이에요. 정말 그렇죠? 엔지니어와 프로덕트 매니저(PMs)를 다른 어떤 직무와 비교해 보면 보수나 지분(equity), 현금(cash) 등 모든 면에서 두세 배(2~3배) 차이가 나요. 그렇게 보면 이 엄청나게 비싼 자원을 신경 써서 지원하고 잘 활용하지 않는다면, 솔직히 그건 죄나 마찬가지예요.
text_zh: 工程师绝对是公司里最贵的资源，没有之一，对吧？你看看工程师的配置，还有产品经理(PM)，跟其他岗位比起来，股权啊现金啊什么的，都是人家的两三倍。这么想的话，要是你不好好照顾这些最贵的宝贝疙瘩，不充分利用他们，那简直就是暴殄天物啊。
text_es: Los ingenieros son, por mucho, el recurso más caro de la empresa. Y cuando digo por mucho, es en serio, ¿verdad? O sea, si te fijas en la composición de ingenieros versus... y PMs versus cualquier otra función, estamos hablando de dos a tres veces más - acciones, efectivo, todo. Y si lo ves de esa manera, pues si no estás cuidando y alimentando y no estás aprovechando al máximo este recurso tan caro e increíble, eso es un crimen.
context: Lenny asks when startups should hire their first PM, and Gokul explains why it's typically when you have 8-10 engineers. He emphasizes that engineers are the most expensive resource at any company in terms of compensation and equity, so if a founder doesn't have bandwidth to properly manage and direct this expensive team, they need to hire a PM to ensure these resources are being leveraged effectively.
vocabulary_highlights: caring and feeding, leveraging this amazing most expensive resource, that's a crime

speaker: Gokul Rajaram
speaker_expertise: Product Management, Company Building, Venture Capital
text: I always feel that you should hire to solve a problem you're facing. You should never hire... Or you feel you're going to face. But especially I think just over-hiring, especially... You want to be efficient and smaller teams are always good. Smaller companies are always good, part of the problem.
text_ko: 저는 항상 지금 당면한 문제를 해결하려고 사람을 뽑아야 한다고 생각해요. 앞으로 닥칠 것 같아서 미리 뽑는 건 하지 말아야 해요. 특히 과잉 채용(over-hiring)은 정말 문제라고 봐요. 효율적으로 운영하려면 팀은 작을수록 좋고, 작은 조직이 더 잘 돌아가는 경우가 많아요. 과도한 채용이 문제의 한 부분이기도 해요.
text_zh: 我一直觉得吧，招人应该是为了解决你现在面临的问题。千万别为了...或者说你觉得可能会遇到的问题就招人。特别是那种过度招聘，真的...你得追求效率，小团队总是好的。小公司也总是有优势的，这也是问题的一部分。
text_es: Siempre pienso que debes contratar para resolver un problema que tienes encima. Nunca deberías contratar... O que sientes que vas a enfrentar. Pero sobre todo creo que contratar de más, especialmente... Quieres ser eficiente y los equipos pequeños siempre funcionan bien. Las empresas pequeñas siempre son buenas, parte del problema.
context: Lenny asks what signals indicate it's time to hire a PM beyond the 8-10 engineer rule of thumb. Gokul emphasizes a fundamental hiring principle - only hire when you have a specific problem that needs solving, rather than hiring preemptively. He warns against over-hiring and stresses that maintaining lean, efficient teams is crucial for startup success.
vocabulary_highlights: over-hiring

speaker: Gokul Rajaram
speaker_expertise: Product Management, Company Building, Venture Capital
text: I think once you have three to four PMs, you do want those three to four PMs to report to a functional product leader just because I feel they want a mentor, first of all. They want a coach. And you want to build a product culture and hopefully discipline across those four or five PMs because the leverage you get.
text_ko: 제 생각에는 프로덕트 매니저들(PMs)이 세 명에서 네 명 정도로 늘어나면, 그분들이 실무 중심의 프로덕트 리더(functional product leader)에게 보고하게 하는 게 좋아요. 우선 멘토가 필요하고, 코치도 원하거든요. 또 그 네다섯 명의 프로덕트 매니저들 사이에 프로덕트 문화(product culture)와 어느 정도의 규율을 만들어야 해요. 그래야 얻는 레버리지(leverage)가 커요.
text_zh: 我觉得一旦你有三四个产品经理(PM)的时候，你肯定希望这三四个PM都汇报给一个专门负责产品的领导，因为我感觉他们首先需要一个导师嘛，需要有人指导他们。而且你也想在这四五个PM中间建立起产品文化，最好还能形成一套规范，这样你能发挥出来的杠杆效应就大了。
text_es: Yo creo que una vez que tienes tres o cuatro PMs, sí quieres que esos tres o cuatro PMs le reporten a un líder funcional de producto, principalmente porque siento que necesitan un mentor, para empezar. Necesitan un coach. Y quieres crear una cultura de producto y ojalá disciplina entre esos cuatro o cinco PMs por todo el leverage que obtienes.
context: Lenny asks about organizational structures as PM teams grow, specifically when PMs should report to a CPO versus a GM. Gokul explains that once you reach 3-4 PMs, they need a dedicated functional leader who can mentor them and build consistent product culture and practices across the team, rather than reporting to a GM who manages multiple functions.
vocabulary_highlights: functional product leader, build a product culture, the leverage you get

speaker: Gokul Rajaram
speaker_expertise: Product Management, Company Building, Venture Capital
text: When companies ask me... Because the number one, if you ever ask a company, 'What's the thing that's keeping you up at night?' They'll always say one of the things always that's keeping them at night, 'I want to hire a leader for X, Y, Z function.' And I never respond with, here's a person. I'll always say, 'Well, you're in this space selling to this kind of customer or serving this kind of customer. Let's think about the best in class companies, who's also, who's very good at functionally the thing you're hiring for, serving the similar type of customer.'
text_ko: 기업들이 제게 물어볼 때가 있어요. 사실 가장 흔한 질문이 뭔지 아세요? 회사에 '요즘 밤잠을 설치게 하는 게 뭐예요?'라고 물어보면 거의 항상 돌아오는 답이 있어요. 'X, Y, Z 기능(function)을 맡을 리더를 뽑고 싶어요.' 저는 절대 '이 사람이요' 하며 특정 인물을 바로 제안하지 않아요. 대신에 이렇게 말해요. '지금 여러분은 이 분야에서 이런 유형의 고객에게 판매(selling)하거나 서비스를 제공하고 있으니, 같은 유형의 고객을 잘 상대하면서도 기능적으로 여러분이 찾는 일을 잘 해내는 '베스트 인 클래스(best-in-class)' 회사를 함께 생각해 봅시다.'
text_zh: 每当公司来找我的时候...因为第一点，如果你问任何一家公司，"什么事情让你夜不能寐？"他们总是会说其中一件让他们睡不着的事就是，"我想为某某某职能招一个领导。"我从来不会直接回答说，这里有个人选。我总是会说，"好，你们在这个领域，服务的是这类客户。咱们想想那些最顶尖的公司，谁在你们要招的这个职能上做得特别好，而且服务的也是类似的客户群体。"
text_es: Cuando las empresas me consultan... Porque lo número uno, si alguna vez le preguntas a una empresa '¿Qué es lo que no te deja dormir por las noches?', siempre van a decir una de las cosas que los desvela: 'Quiero contratar a un líder para tal o cual función.' Y yo nunca respondo con 'aquí tienes a esta persona.' Siempre les digo: 'Bueno, ustedes están en este sector vendiendo a este tipo de cliente o atendiendo a este tipo de cliente. Pensemos en las empresas que son referentes en el mercado, ¿quién es realmente bueno funcionalmente en lo que están buscando contratar y que atiende a un tipo de cliente similar?'
context: Lenny asks about Gokul's approach to helping companies hire leaders, referencing a popular Twitter thread. Gokul explains his methodology - instead of recommending specific people, he helps companies identify best-in-class companies that excel at the function they're hiring for while serving similar customer types. This allows them to target the right talent pools rather than just looking at direct competitors.
vocabulary_highlights: keeping you up at night, best in class companies

speaker: Graham Weaver
text: I think the time to quit is when you can no longer see the vision and you can no longer really believe the vision. And then when that happens for a long period of time ... or maybe you're no longer even excited about the vision; somewhere in there, I think. The excited one, you have to be a little careful of, because in the dark days, exciting is not the word you're going to use.
text_ko: 그만둘 때는 비전(vision)이 더 이상 보이지 않고, 진짜로 그 비전을 믿을 수 없을 때라고 생각해요. 그 상태가 오래 지속되거나, 혹은 그 비전에 대해 더 이상 설레지 않을 때쯤—대체로 그쯤인 것 같아요. 다만 '설렘'에 대해서는 좀 조심해야 해요. 힘든 시기에는 '설레다'는 말을 쓰지 않게 되니까요.
text_zh: 我觉得该退出的时候就是当你看不到愿景了，也不再相信这个愿景的时候。如果这种状态持续很长时间...或者你对这个愿景已经没什么激情了，差不多就是这个意思吧。不过那个激情这个说法得小心点，因为在最艰难的时候，激情这个词你肯定是用不上的。
text_es: Creo que es hora de dejarlo cuando ya no puedes ver la visión y ya no crees realmente en ella. Y cuando eso pasa durante mucho tiempo... o tal vez ya ni siquiera te emociona la visión; por ahí va la cosa, creo yo. Con lo de la emoción hay que tener cuidado, porque en los días difíciles, "emocionante" no es precisamente la palabra que vas a usar.
context: Lenny asks Graham when someone should quit something, since some things are just not worth pursuing. Graham explains that the decision to quit should be based on whether you can still see and believe in your vision, rather than temporary setbacks or lack of excitement during difficult periods. He emphasizes that excitement isn't a reliable indicator during challenging times, but losing faith in the fundamental vision over an extended period is a clearer signal.
vocabulary_highlights: dark days, you have to be a little careful of

speaker: Graham Weaver
text: You start off and you're unconscious, and you're kind of going through the motions. And you may not even realize why you're doing what you're doing or even realize what you're doing. So for example, a typical person gets up, they have whatever their morning routine ... I get up out, work out, take a shower, drive into work, fight traffic, commute.
text_ko: 처음에는 무의식적으로 시작해서 그냥 관성적으로 움직여요. 왜 그렇게 하는지, 지금 뭘 하고 있는지조차 잘 모를 때가 있어요. 예를 들어 보통 사람은 일어나서 각자 아침 루틴을 하고… 저는 일어나서 운동하고 샤워하고 차로 출근해서 차 막히는 길을 뚫으며 통근해요.
text_zh: 刚开始的时候，你就是无意识地在过日子，基本上就是在走过场。你可能都不知道自己为什么要做这些事，甚至都没意识到自己在干嘛。比如说，一个普通人起床后，就按照他那套晨间流程...我起床、健身、洗澡、开车上班、堵车、通勤，就这样。
text_es: Al principio estás como en piloto automático, simplemente sigues la rutina sin pensar. Y puede que ni siquiera te des cuenta de por qué haces lo que haces, o incluso qué estás haciendo realmente. Por ejemplo, una persona típica se levanta, tiene su rutina matutina... me levanto, hago ejercicio, me ducho, manejo al trabajo, me peleo con el tráfico, hago mi traslado diario.
context: Lenny asks Graham to explain his concept of 'autopilot mode' - the idea that most people go through life unconsciously without intentional direction. Graham describes how people can become unconscious and simply go through daily motions without realizing what they're doing or why. He uses the example of a typical workday routine to illustrate how people can live mechanically rather than intentionally.
vocabulary_highlights: going through the motions, fight traffic

speaker: Graham Weaver
text: The formula, I think, for greatness is to be intentional, get in the path of the thing that you're most excited about, and then give yourself several decades to do it. And that's based on investing in 600 companies and building my own business.
text_ko: 제가 생각하는 위대해지는 공식은 의도적으로 움직이고, 가장 가슴 뛰는 일의 길로 들어서서 그걸 해내기 위해 스스로에게 수십 년의 시간을 허락하는 거예요. 이 말은 제가 600여 개 회사에 투자하고 제 사업을 키워온 경험을 바탕으로 한 말이에요.
text_zh: 我觉得成就伟大的公式就是，要有明确的目标，然后去追求那个最让你兴奋的事情，再给自己几十年的时间去做这件事。这是我投资了600家公司、创建自己企业后得出的心得。
text_es: Creo que la fórmula para la grandeza es ser intencional, ponerte en el camino de lo que más te emociona, y luego darte varias décadas para hacerlo. Y esto lo digo después de invertir en 600 empresas y construir mi propio negocio.
context: Lenny mentions Graham's highly successful private equity fund performance and asks for comment. Graham responds by sharing what he believes is the fundamental formula for achieving greatness, based on his extensive experience investing in hundreds of companies and building his own business over decades. He emphasizes that this advice comes from real-world results, not just theoretical knowledge.
vocabulary_highlights: get in the path of

speaker: Graham Weaver
text: Pick anything. You want a better body? Okay, you're going to need to go to the gym. When you go to the gym the first few times, it's going to not be that fun. The first move is negative. If I'm optimizing for tomorrow and I just want to have a great day tomorrow, I'm going to stay exactly where I am.
text_ko: 뭘 하든 마찬가지예요. 더 나은 몸을 원해요? 그럼 헬스장(gym)에 가야 해요. 처음 몇 번은 별로 즐겁지 않을 거고, 첫 걸음은 오히려 손해처럼 느껴질 거예요. 만약 제가 '내일'만을 위해 최적화(optimizing for tomorrow)해서 내일 하루만 좋게 만들고 싶다면, 전 지금 있는 자리 그대로 머물러 있을 거예요.
text_zh: 随便举个例子吧。你想要更好的身材？那行，你就得去健身房。刚开始去健身房的那几次，肯定不会很爽的。第一步总是痛苦的。如果我只想着明天过得舒服点，只想明天开心，那我就会一直待在原地不动。
text_es: Elige lo que sea. ¿Quieres estar en mejor forma? Bueno, vas a tener que ir al gimnasio. Cuando vayas al gym las primeras veces, no va a ser nada divertido. El primer paso siempre cuesta. Si solo me enfoco en pasarla bien mañana y quiero que sea un día genial, me voy a quedar exactamente donde estoy.
context: Lenny references Graham's quote about 'everything you want is on the other side of worse first' and asks him to explain it. Graham illustrates this concept by explaining that any worthwhile change requires initial discomfort or difficulty. He uses the example of getting in shape to show how the first steps toward improvement are often unpleasant, and if you optimize for short-term comfort, you'll never make meaningful progress.
vocabulary_highlights: the first move is negative, optimizing for tomorrow

speaker: Graham Weaver
text: And I have this unbelievable statement. I didn't write it. Dan and Chip Heath wrote it in their book, Switch, which is 'Scale your bright spots. Find what's working and do more of that.' And as you start to progress, for me, for example, at Alpine, almost all the time, we always had at least a small glimmer of a bright spot.
text_ko: 믿기 어려운 말이 하나 있어요. 제가 쓴 건 아니고요. 댄과 칩 히스가 쓴 책 '스위치(Switch)'에 이런 구절이 나와요: "성공 사례(bright spots)를 확장하세요. 잘 되고 있는 걸 찾아서 그걸 더 하세요." 그리고 일이 진척될수록, 제 경우 알파인(Alpine)에서는 거의 항상 적어도 작은 성공 사례(bright spot) 하나쯤은 있었어요.
text_zh: 我有一句特别棒的话，不是我说的，是丹和奇普·希思在他们的《转变》这本书里写的：'放大你的亮点。找到有效的东西，然后多做这些。'当你开始有进展的时候，就拿我在Alpine的经验来说，几乎所有时候，我们总能找到至少一丝丝的亮点。
text_es: Y tengo esta frase increíble. Yo no la escribí. Dan y Chip Heath la escribieron en su libro, Switch, que dice 'Escala tus puntos brillantes. Encuentra lo que está funcionando y haz más de eso.' Y conforme empiezas a avanzar, por ejemplo en mi caso, en Alpine, casi siempre, siempre teníamos por lo menos un pequeño destello de esperanza, algo que brillaba.
context: Graham is explaining when to quit versus when to persist with something difficult. He shares a key principle from the book 'Switch' about focusing on what's working rather than what's failing. He uses his own company Alpine as an example, explaining that even during the first difficult 10 years, they could always identify small successes or 'bright spots' that they could build upon and scale.
vocabulary_highlights: scale your bright spots, small glimmer

speaker: Graham Weaver
text: The thing that we probably believe to be true that not that many people agree with us on is that the management team is really where we think all the alpha comes from. You can't get the industry wrong, because if you hire the best management team in the world to run a typewriter business, you're going to lose money.
text_ko: 많은 사람이 동의하지 않을 수도 있는데, 저희는 모든 알파(alpha)가 경영팀(management team)에서 나온다고 생각해요. 다만 업종을 잘못 고르면 소용없어요. 세상에서 가장 뛰어난 경영팀을 데려와서 타자기 사업(typewriter business)을 맡겨도 결국 돈을 잃게 돼요.
text_zh: 我们坚信但可能很多人不认同的一点是，管理团队才是真正创造超额收益(alpha)的关键。当然了，你不能选错行业，就算你找来全世界最牛的管理团队去经营打字机生意，那肯定还是要亏钱的。
text_es: Lo que nosotros creemos que es cierto, pero en lo que no mucha gente está de acuerdo con nosotros, es que el equipo directivo es realmente de donde pensamos que viene todo el alfa (alpha). No puedes equivocarte con la industria, porque si contratas al mejor equipo de gestión del mundo para manejar un negocio de máquinas de escribir, vas a perder dinero.
context: Lenny asks Graham what his private equity firm looks for in companies that others might not focus on. Graham explains Alpine's distinctive investment philosophy - that exceptional management teams are the primary source of returns (alpha). He clarifies that while you can't choose a completely failing industry, having world-class leadership is more important than finding the perfect market opportunity.
vocabulary_highlights: all the alpha comes from

speaker: Grant Lee
speaker_expertise: Marketing Strategy, Product Management, Growth Strategy
text: All the initial influencers, I onboarded manually myself. I would jump on a call with each one of them so that they understood what Gamma represented, how to use the product. You want to be able to have them tell you story but in their voice. I think a lot of people think influencer marketing and they'll think these big trendy creators, people that have a million followers. This is the wrong approach. You basically give them a script to read, immediately feels like an ad.
text_ko: 초기 인플루언서들은 제가 직접 하나하나 온보딩(onboarding)했어요. 각 인플루언서와 통화하면서 Gamma가 무엇을 대표하는지, 제품을 어떻게 사용하는지 확실히 이해하게 하려고 했어요. 중요한 건 그들이 자기 목소리로 이야기를 하게 만드는 거예요. 많은 분들이 인플루언서 마케팅(influencer marketing)을 떠올리면 팔로워가 백만 명인 트렌디한 크리에이터들만 생각하는데, 그건 잘못된 접근이에요. 사실상 읽을 스크립트(script)를 주면 바로 광고(ad)처럼 느껴져요.
text_zh: 最开始那些意见领袖，我都是一个一个亲自去谈的。我会跟每个人单独打电话，让他们真正理解Gamma是做什么的，产品怎么用。你得让他们用自己的话来讲你的故事，而不是照本宣科。很多人一提到网红营销(influencer marketing)，就想到那些很火的大V，动不动就几百万粉丝的。这种思路是错的。你直接给他们一个稿子让他们念，马上就变成硬广了。
text_es: Todos los primeros influencers los incorporé yo mismo, uno por uno. Me subía a una llamada con cada uno para que entendieran qué representaba Gamma, cómo usar el producto. Lo que buscas es que te cuenten tu historia pero con su propia voz. Creo que mucha gente piensa en marketing de influencers y se imagina estos creadores súper trendy, gente que tiene un millón de seguidores. Ese enfoque está mal. Básicamente les das un guión para leer y de inmediato se siente como un anuncio.
context: Lenny asks Grant about Gamma's influencer marketing strategy, which was a key growth lever for the company. Grant explains his hands-on approach to working with influencers and why targeting micro-influencers is more effective than working with large creators. He emphasizes the importance of authenticity in influencer partnerships rather than treating them as simple advertising placements.
vocabulary_highlights: onboarded manually, tell you story but in their voice, big trendy creators, immediately feels like an ad

speaker: Grant Lee
speaker_expertise: Marketing Strategy, Product Management, Growth Strategy
text: You're much better doing the hard thing, which is hard to scale, finding the thousands of micro influencers that have an audience where your product maybe is actually useful. People really trust what they say. That ends up becoming this wildfire that can spread really, really fast.
text_ko: 차라리 확장하기(스케일(scale))는 어렵고 손이 많이 가는 그런 일을 하는 게 훨씬 낫아요. 예를 들어 수천 명의 마이크로 인플루언서(micro influencers)를 찾아서, 우리 제품이 실제로 유용할 수 있는 오디언스를 가진 팔로워들에게 닿게 하는 거예요. 사람들은 그들이 하는 말을 정말로 신뢰하거든요. 그러면 그게 금세, 아주 빠르게 퍼지는 들불처럼 번져요.
text_zh: 你最好还是做那些难做的事儿，虽然不好规模化，但要去找那些成千上万的小网红(micro influencers)，他们的粉丝群体可能真的会用得上你的产品。大家特别信任他们说的话。这样搞下去，就会像野火一样蔓延，传播得特别特别快。
text_es: Es mucho mejor hacer lo difícil, que es complicado de escalar, encontrar a esos miles de micro influencers que tienen una audiencia donde tu producto realmente puede ser útil. La gente confía muchísimo en lo que dicen. Eso termina convirtiéndose en un incendio forestal que se puede extender súper rápido.
context: Grant continues explaining his influencer marketing philosophy, contrasting his approach with traditional influencer marketing. He advocates for working with micro-influencers who have smaller but more engaged audiences that genuinely trust their recommendations. He describes how this strategy creates organic word-of-mouth growth that can spread rapidly through communities.
vocabulary_highlights: hard to scale, micro influencers, wildfire that can spread

speaker: Grant Lee
speaker_expertise: Marketing Strategy, Product Management, Growth Strategy
text: We would have an idea in the morning, come up with some sort of functional prototype, recruit a bunch of people that are legitimately good prospective users, but have zero skin in the game, ship fast so people can start playing with it. In the afternoon, we're already running pretty full scale experiment. You start actually hearing other people describe their usage of the product. We can also watch them struggle.
text_ko: 아침에 아이디어가 떠오르면, 어떤 식으로든 기능적 프로토타입(functional prototype)을 만들어서 실제로 적합한 잠재 사용자들(prospective users)을 여럿 모집해요. 다만 그들은 위험 부담(skin in the game)은 전혀 없어요. 사람들이 바로 써보게 하기 위해 빨리 출시(ship fast)하죠. 오후가 되면 이미 꽤 대규모 실험(full-scale experiment)을 돌리고 있어요. 사람들이 제품을 어떻게 쓰는지 직접 얘기하는 걸 듣게 되고, 그들이 애먹는 모습도 지켜볼 수 있어요.
text_zh: 我们早上想到一个点子，马上就能搞出个能用的原型(prototype)，然后找一帮真正的潜在用户来测试——这些人都很合适，但跟我们没有任何利害关系，快速上线让大家先玩起来。到了下午，我们就已经在跑大规模的实验了。这时候你就能听到其他人真实地描述他们怎么用这个产品，也能看到他们在使用过程中遇到的各种问题。
text_es: Teníamos una idea por la mañana, armábamos algún tipo de prototipo funcional, reclutábamos a un montón de gente que realmente eran buenos usuarios potenciales, pero que no tenían nada que ver con el proyecto, lanzábamos rápido para que la gente pudiera empezar a probarlo. Ya por la tarde, estábamos corriendo experimentos a gran escala. Empezabas a escuchar cómo otras personas describían su uso del producto. También podíamos verlos batallar con él.
context: Lenny asks Grant about Gamma's experimental approach to product development. Grant describes their rapid prototyping and user testing workflow, where they can go from idea to user feedback within a single day. This process involves recruiting unbiased potential users to test prototypes and observe their real interactions with the product, allowing the team to identify usability issues quickly.
vocabulary_highlights: functional prototype, zero skin in the game, ship fast, full scale experiment, watch them struggle

speaker: Grant Lee
speaker_expertise: Marketing Strategy, Product Management, Growth Strategy
text: I think most people today are probably familiar with founder-led sales, which is still very, very important. I think before you hire your first salesperson or AE, it's great for the founder to understand what it takes. And they're going to craft the right narrative, the right story.
text_ko: 요즘 대부분 사람들은 창업자 주도 영업(founder-led sales)에 익숙할 거예요. 이 방식은 여전히 정말 중요해요. 첫 영업사원(salesperson)이나 AE(Account Executive, AE)를 채용하기 전에 창업자가 직접 무엇이 필요한지 이해해 보는 게 좋아요. 그래야 적절한 내러티브(narrative)와 스토리(story)를 만들어낼 수 있어요.
text_zh: 我觉得现在大部分人应该都知道创始人亲自做销售这回事，这个确实还是非常非常重要的。我觉得在你招第一个销售或者AE之前，创始人自己先搞明白这里面的门道是很有必要的。而且他们会找到最合适的说辞，讲出最打动人的故事。
text_es: Creo que la mayoría de la gente hoy en día ya conoce las ventas lideradas por el fundador (founder-led sales), que siguen siendo súper importantes. Me parece que antes de contratar a tu primer vendedor o AE (account executive), está genial que el fundador entienda lo que se necesita. Y van a crear la narrativa correcta, la historia adecuada.
context: Grant explains the concept of founder-led marketing by drawing parallels to founder-led sales. He argues that just as founders should understand sales before hiring salespeople, they should also understand marketing and storytelling before delegating these functions. This hands-on approach helps founders develop better narratives and maintain higher standards when working with marketing professionals or influencers.
vocabulary_highlights: founder-led sales, craft the right narrative

speaker: Grant Lee
speaker_expertise: Marketing Strategy, Product Management, Growth Strategy
text: I think there's that saying where obviously if you can have that clarity, that's super important. And most people will try to get super creative with their copywriting, but that's not usually the right way to break through and communicate something. So how do you improve your own copywriting?
text_ko: 어떤 말이 있잖아요, 메시지를 명확하게 전달할 수 있다면 그게 정말 중요하다고요. 많은 사람들이 카피라이팅(copywriting)을 엄청 창의적으로만 하려고 하는데, 사실 그게 보통은 주목을 끌거나 제대로 전달하는 방법은 아니에요. 그럼 자신의 카피라이팅(copywriting)은 어떻게 개선하면 좋을까요?
text_zh: 我觉得有句话说得对，显然如果你能把话说清楚，这个超级重要。很多人写文案的时候总想搞得特别有创意，但其实这通常不是突围和传达信息的正确方式。那么怎么提升自己的文案写作(copywriting)能力呢？
text_es: Creo que hay un dicho que dice que si puedes tener esa claridad, es súper importante. Y la mayoría de la gente trata de ponerse muy creativa con su copywriting, pero normalmente esa no es la forma correcta de destacar y comunicar algo. Entonces, ¿cómo mejoras tu propio copywriting?
context: Grant discusses the importance of clear communication in founder-led marketing. He references the principle of prioritizing clarity over creativity in copywriting, suggesting that founders should focus on being understood rather than being clever. This advice comes in the context of explaining how founders can develop better marketing skills by practicing copywriting themselves.
vocabulary_highlights: break through and communicate, improve your own copywriting

speaker: Grant Lee
speaker_expertise: Marketing Strategy, Product Management, Growth Strategy
text: I think what I've learned is, even for LinkedIn versus Twitter, the audiences want different things. And so you almost have to then have different tones of voices or even nuggets or sharing. For me, I invested much more in LinkedIn early on just because it felt a little bit more natural for me. And then over time I said, 'Okay, well I'm going to start packaging certain content for Twitter that's actually different than what I would post on LinkedIn.'
text_ko: 제가 배운 건 LinkedIn이든 Twitter든 청중이 원하는 게 서로 다르다는 점이에요. 그래서 거의 다른 톤(tones of voice)이나 공유 방식, 심지어는 소소한 콘텐츠 조각들(nuggets)까지 달리 가져가야 하더라고요. 저는 초반에 LinkedIn에 훨씬 더 투자했어요. 그쪽이 저한테 더 자연스럽게 느껴졌거든요. 그러다 시간이 지나면서 '트위터에는 LinkedIn에 올리는 것과는 다른 형태로 특정 콘텐츠를 따로 패키징(packaging)해서 올리자'고 생각했어요.
text_zh: 我觉得我学到的是，LinkedIn和Twitter(推特)的用户群体想要的东西是不一样的。所以你几乎得用不同的语调，甚至分享不同的内容点。对我来说，我一开始在LinkedIn上投入得更多，因为感觉更适合我。后来我就想，"好吧，我要开始为Twitter专门包装一些内容，跟我在LinkedIn上发的要有所区别。"
text_es: Creo que lo que he aprendido es que, incluso entre LinkedIn y Twitter, las audiencias quieren cosas distintas. Entonces casi que tienes que manejar diferentes tonos o incluso diferentes tipos de contenido. En mi caso, yo invertí mucho más en LinkedIn desde el principio porque se me hacía más natural. Y luego con el tiempo me dije: "Bueno, ahora voy a empezar a adaptar cierto contenido específicamente para Twitter que sea diferente a lo que subiría en LinkedIn."
context: Grant shares his approach to social media marketing across different platforms. He explains how he learned that LinkedIn and Twitter audiences have different preferences and expectations, requiring tailored content strategies for each platform. This insight led him to develop platform-specific approaches rather than simply cross-posting the same content everywhere.
vocabulary_highlights: different tones of voices, nuggets or sharing, packaging certain content

speaker: Guillermo Rauch
speaker_expertise: AI/ML Products, Engineering Leadership, Community Building
text: Taste, sometimes I think we think of as this inaccessible thing that, "Oh, that person was born with taste." I see it as a skill that it can develop. I think is extremely important to try lots of products. We have one of our internal operating principles as increasing exposure hours. Try to quantify how much time you expose yourself to watching how people use your products and you'll develop that muscle.
text_ko: 미적 감각은 가끔 '그 사람은 타고났어' 하고 도달할 수 없는 것으로 여겨지는 것 같아요. 저는 미적 감각을 개발할 수 있는 기술이라고 봐요. 여러 제품을 많이 써보는 게 정말 중요하다고 생각해요. 우리 회사의 내부 운영 원칙(internal operating principles) 중 하나는 노출 시간(exposure hours)을 늘리는 거예요. 사람들이 우리 제품을 어떻게 쓰는지 지켜보는 데 자신을 얼마나 노출시키는지, 그 시간을 정량화해 보세요. 그러면 그 근육이 길러져요.
text_zh: 品味这个东西，有时候我觉得大家都认为这是天生的，觉得"哎呀，那个人就是天生有品味"。但我把它看成是一种可以培养的技能。我觉得多体验各种产品特别重要。我们有一个内部运营原则叫做增加接触时长(increasing exposure hours)。你要量化一下自己花了多少时间去观察用户怎么使用你的产品，这样你就能锻炼出这种感觉来。
text_es: El buen gusto, a veces creo que lo vemos como algo inalcanzable, como "ay, esa persona nació con buen gusto." Yo lo veo como una habilidad que se puede desarrollar. Creo que es súper importante probar muchos productos. Tenemos uno de nuestros principios operativos internos que es aumentar las horas de exposición (exposure hours). Trata de cuantificar cuánto tiempo te expones a observar cómo la gente usa tus productos y vas a desarrollar ese músculo.
context: Lenny asks Guillermo about building taste, a quality people often struggle to develop when creating products. Guillermo explains that taste isn't an innate gift but rather a developable skill. He shares Vercel's internal principle of "increasing exposure hours" - deliberately spending time observing how people interact with products to build better product intuition.
vocabulary_highlights: inaccessible thing, exposure hours, develop that muscle

speaker: Guillermo Rauch
speaker_expertise: AI/ML Products, Engineering Leadership, Community Building
text: A lot of the programming jobs to be done that used to be specializations, I think, are going away, in a way. They're translation tasks, but knowing how things work under the hood is going to be very important for you because you're going to be able to influence the model and make it follow your intention a lot better.
text_ko: 예전엔 전문화된 일이었던 많은 프로그래밍 업무들이, 어떤 면에선 사라지고 있는 것 같아요. 그런 일들이 번역 작업(translation tasks) 같은 성격이긴 한데, 내부 작동 방식(under the hood)을 아는 건 아주 중요해질 거예요. 그래야 모델(model)에 영향을 줘서 여러분의 의도(intention)를 훨씬 더 잘 따르게 만들 수 있으니까요.
text_zh: 我觉得以前那些需要专门技能的编程工作，很多都在慢慢消失。它们更像是翻译任务了，但是你得真正懂底层原理，这对你来说会非常重要，因为只有这样你才能更好地引导模型，让它按照你的想法去执行。
text_es: Muchos de los trabajos de programación que antes eran especializaciones, creo que van a desaparecer, de cierta manera. Son tareas de traducción, pero saber cómo funcionan las cosas por dentro va a ser súper importante para ti porque vas a poder influir en el modelo y lograr que siga tu intención mucho mejor.
context: Lenny asks about the future of engineering careers and whether people should still learn to code. Guillermo explains that many programming tasks are essentially translation jobs (like converting designs to code) that AI can now handle. However, he emphasizes that understanding the underlying systems and technologies remains crucial because this knowledge helps you communicate more effectively with AI models.
vocabulary_highlights: jobs to be done, under the hood, follow your intention

speaker: Guillermo Rauch
speaker_expertise: AI/ML Products, Engineering Leadership, Community Building
text: People could be more full stack. Imagine a designer that can ship a fully baked product, a product manager that can prototype and ship to production. We shouldn't put limits on ourselves and what we can build, and what we can ship, and what we can dream about making possible on these web surfaces.
text_ko: 사람들이 더 풀스택(full stack)이 될 수 있어요. 예를 들어 완성된 제품을 직접 배포(ship)할 수 있는 디자이너나, 프로토타입(prototype)을 만들고 그대로 프로덕션(production)에 배포(ship)할 수 있는 프로덕트 매니저(product manager)를 상상해 보세요. 우리 자신이나 우리가 만들고 배포할 수 있는 것, 그리고 이 웹 환경(web surfaces)에서 가능하다고 꿈꿀 수 있는 것에 제한을 두면 안 돼요.
text_zh: 其实大家都可以变得更全能一些。你想想，如果一个设计师能够独立交付一个完整的产品，一个产品经理能够自己做原型还能直接上线，那该多牛。我们不应该给自己设限，不管是开发能力、交付能力，还是在web端实现各种可能性的想象力，都不应该有界限。
text_es: La gente podría ser más full stack. Imagínate un diseñador que pueda sacar un producto completamente terminado, un product manager que pueda hacer prototipos y llevarlos a producción. No deberíamos ponernos límites sobre lo que podemos construir, lo que podemos lanzar, y lo que podemos soñar con hacer posible en estas plataformas web.
context: Lenny asks how AI tools like v0 will change product development for product managers and teams. Guillermo envisions a future where traditional role boundaries blur, enabled by AI tools that make it easier to build and ship products. He believes people will become more versatile, with designers able to create complete products and product managers able to build working prototypes.
vocabulary_highlights: more full stack, fully baked product, put limits on ourselves

speaker: Guillermo Rauch
speaker_expertise: AI/ML Products, Engineering Leadership, Community Building
text: One of the bets that I made early on with Vercel that really paid off is Vercel, maybe as a metaphor is like AWS in easy mode for a lot of people. We have a very large user base of people that would have otherwise not have been able to configure all of the ins and outs of the cloud, but do want the scale, flexibility, speed, et cetera.
text_ko: 제가 Vercel과 함께 초기에 한 베팅 중 하나가 정말 성공적이었는데, Vercel은 많은 사람들에게 AWS의 쉬운 모드 같은 느낌이에요. 클라우드의 복잡한 설정을 할 수 없었던 많은 사용자들이 있지만, 그들은 여전히 규모, 유연성, 속도 같은 것들을 원하거든요.
text_zh: 我早期在Vercel上押的一个宝，现在看来真的押对了。打个比方，Vercel就像是简化版的AWS，对很多人来说特别好用。我们有一大批用户，他们本来搞不定云服务那些复杂的配置，但又想要规模化、灵活性、速度这些好处，Vercel正好满足了他们的需求。
text_es: Una de las apuestas que hice desde el principio con Vercel y que realmente dio resultado es que Vercel, como metáfora, es como AWS pero en modo fácil para mucha gente. Tenemos una base de usuarios enorme de personas que de otra manera no habrían podido configurar todos los detalles técnicos de la nube, pero sí quieren la escalabilidad, flexibilidad, velocidad y todo eso.
context: Guillermo explains Vercel's positioning in the market and how they've made complex cloud infrastructure accessible to more developers. He describes how Vercel simplifies cloud deployment compared to AWS, allowing developers to reach massive scale without needing deep infrastructure knowledge, citing the example of a customer handling 43X traffic increases seamlessly.
vocabulary_highlights: really paid off, easy mode, ins and outs of the cloud

speaker: Guillermo Rauch
speaker_expertise: AI/ML Products, Engineering Leadership, Community Building
text: The secrets of product quality is blood, sweat, and tears. The other thing is that a great product is made up of a thousand little details and so you're never really done. There's a humility that comes from the process also of why the best product builders will say nine nos for every yes. Because when you say yes, it's like adopting a puppy.
text_ko: 제품 품질의 비결은 피와 땀과 눈물이에요. 그리고 훌륭한 제품은 천 가지 작은 디테일로 이루어져 있어서 사실 끝난 적이 없어요. 그 과정에서 겸손이 생기기도 하는데, 그래서 최고의 프로덕트 빌더들(product builders)은 '예스' 하나에 '노' 아홉 개를 말한다고 해요. '예스'를 한다는 건 강아지를 입양하는 것과 같거든요.
text_zh: 产品质量的秘诀就是要下血本，真的是汗水和泪水都要付出。还有就是一个好产品是由无数个小细节堆起来的，所以你永远都做不完。这个过程也会让人变得谦逊，这就是为什么最厉害的产品经理十个想法里要否掉九个，只留一个的原因。因为你一旦说"行"，就像是收养了一只小狗一样，要负责到底。
text_es: Los secretos de la calidad del producto son sangre, sudor y lágrimas. Lo otro es que un gran producto se compone de mil pequeños detalles, así que nunca realmente terminas. También hay una humildad que viene del proceso, por eso los mejores desarrolladores de productos dicen nueve "no" por cada "sí". Porque cuando dices que sí, es como adoptar un cachorro.
context: Lenny references Guillermo's tweet about product quality requiring "blood, sweat, and tears" and asks him to elaborate. Guillermo explains that building great products requires intense attention to countless small details and involves difficult trade-offs. He uses the metaphor of adopting a puppy to describe how each new feature requires ongoing care and maintenance, which is why successful product builders must be highly selective.
vocabulary_highlights: blood, sweat, and tears, nine nos for every yes, like adopting a puppy

speaker: Guillermo Rauch
speaker_expertise: AI/ML Products, Engineering Leadership, Community Building
text: I foresee a lot of people becoming incredibly impactful in building and shipping amazing products, and building gigantic companies, and everything you could imagine, where a single person can do the job of a hundred different people in a hundred different specializations.
text_ko: 앞으로 많은 사람들이 멋진 제품을 만들고 출시하면서 거대한 회사를 세우고 상상할 수 있는 거의 모든 일을 해내며 엄청난 영향력을 발휘할 것 같아요. 한 사람이 백 명의 서로 다른 전문 분야에서 하던 일을 해낼 수 있는 시대가 올 거예요.
text_zh: 我觉得以后会有很多人变得超级厉害，能做出特别棒的产品，建立巨无霸公司，你能想到的各种事情他们都能做到，一个人就能顶一百个不同专业领域的人。
text_es: Veo que mucha gente va a lograr un impacto increíble creando y lanzando productos espectaculares, construyendo empresas enormes, y todo lo que te puedas imaginar, donde una sola persona va a poder hacer el trabajo de cien personas diferentes en cien especializaciones distintas.
context: Lenny asks about the future of engineering careers and whether people should still learn to code. Guillermo envisions a future where AI tools will dramatically amplify individual productivity, allowing one person to accomplish work that previously required large teams with diverse specializations. He sees this as democratizing the ability to build successful products and companies.
vocabulary_highlights: incredibly impactful, gigantic companies, do the job of a hundred different people

speaker: Gustaf Alströmer
speaker_expertise: Product Strategy, Growth Strategy, Climate Tech
text: If I drill down what makes companies fail, it's quite simple. It's just like they don't talk to users, which means they don't find product market fit. And if they don't find product market fit, nothing else really matters. What mistakes do people make is like it is all about that. It's all about talking to customers and learning that you're building something that's actually useful.
text_ko: 제가 기업들이 실패하는 이유를 파고들어 보면, 사실 굉장히 단순해요. 사용자와 대화하지 않아서 제품-시장 적합성(product-market fit)을 찾지 못하는 거예요. 그걸 찾지 못하면 다른 건 별로 중요하지 않아요. 사람들이 저지르는 실수도 결국 거기에요. 고객과 계속 얘기하면서, 내가 만드는 게 실제로 쓸모 있는지 배우는 게 핵심이에요.
text_zh: 如果我深挖一下公司失败的根本原因，其实很简单。就是他们不跟用户聊天，这就意味着找不到产品市场契合度(product market fit)。如果找不到产品市场契合度(product market fit)，其他什么都白搭。大家犯的错误说白了就是这个。关键就是要跟客户多交流，搞清楚你做的东西到底有没有用。
text_es: Si me pongo a analizar qué es lo que hace que las empresas fracasen, es bastante simple. Es que simplemente no hablan con los usuarios, lo que significa que no logran el ajuste producto-mercado (product market fit). Y si no logran ese ajuste producto-mercado, nada más importa realmente. Los errores que comete la gente van por ahí. Todo se trata de hablar con los clientes y aprender que estás construyendo algo que realmente sirve.
context: Lenny asks Gustaf about the most common mistakes that early stage startups make. Gustaf explains that after working with over 600 startups at Y Combinator, he's identified a clear pattern of failure. He emphasizes that finding product market fit is the fundamental requirement for startup success, and this can only be achieved through consistent customer conversations to understand what people actually want and need.
vocabulary_highlights: drill down, product market fit, nothing else really matters
topics: Starting a Company, Product Management, Decision Making

speaker: Gustaf Alströmer
speaker_expertise: Product Strategy, Growth Strategy, Climate Tech
text: The problem is, which anyone who hasn't done sales before that joined YC, they realize this, is that if you take the average customer group in the world, 90% are not early adopters. It doesn't matter if you have something new and cool, they're just not interested. They are not incentivized to take risks in their job to try something new. They're just incentivized to not take risks and just continue what they're doing.
text_ko: 문제는, YC(Y Combinator)에 합류하기 전까지 영업(sales)을 해본 적이 없는 사람들은 이걸 금방 깨닫게 된다는 거예요. 전 세계 평균 고객층을 보면 90%가 얼리어답터(early adopters)가 아니에요. 아무리 새롭고 멋진 걸 내놔도 그냥 관심이 없어요. 직장에서 새로운 걸 시도하느라 위험을 감수하도록 유리한 인센티브(incentives)가 주어지지 않고, 오히려 위험을 피하고 하던 대로 계속하려는 인센티브가 더 강하게 작용해요.
text_zh: 问题在于，那些没做过销售就加入YC的人都会意识到这一点：全世界的客户群体里，90%都不是早期采用者(early adopters)。不管你的产品多新多酷，他们就是不感兴趣。他们在工作中没有动力去冒险尝试新东西，反而更有动力不去冒险，就按老路子继续做下去。
text_es: El tema es que, cualquiera que no haya hecho ventas antes y que se haya unido a YC se da cuenta de esto: si tomas al grupo promedio de clientes en el mundo, el 90% no son early adopters. No importa si tienes algo nuevo y genial, simplemente no les interesa. No tienen incentivos en su trabajo para tomar riesgos y probar algo nuevo. Al contrario, tienen incentivos para no tomar riesgos y simplemente seguir haciendo lo que ya hacen.
context: Gustaf explains why founders are often afraid to talk to customers and why they get discouraged by rejection. He's describing the reality of customer acquisition - that most potential customers are not early adopters who are willing to try new products. This insight helps founders understand that rejection is normal and expected, not a sign that their product is fundamentally flawed.
vocabulary_highlights: early adopters, incentivized to not take risks
topics: Starting a Company, Growth & Marketing, Learning & Growth

speaker: Gustaf Alströmer
speaker_expertise: Product Strategy, Growth Strategy, Climate Tech
text: I think the truth is that we're not very good at knowing what's going to succeed. Certainly we cannot figure out who's going to be the really successful company in the batch. That's not possible. What we're good at is knowing what failure looks like. What we sometimes like to tell founders at the beginning of the batch is like, 'If you fail, please do it in some new exciting way. Not one that we've seen 100 times.'
text_ko: 사실 우리는 무엇이 성공할지 잘 알지 못해요. 확실히 이번 배치(batch)에서 누가 진짜 크게 성공할 회사가 될지 알아내는 건 불가능해요. 우리가 잘하는 건 실패가 어떤 모습인지 알아보는 거예요. 그래서 배치 초반에 창업자들에게 가끔 이렇게 말해요. "실패한다면 제발 새롭고 흥미로운 방식으로 실패하세요. 우리가 백 번은 본 그런 실패 말고요."
text_zh: 我觉得实话说，我们也不太会预测什么能成功。我们肯定没法看出这一批里哪家公司会真正做大，这根本不可能。但我们擅长的是，一眼就能看出失败是什么样子。所以我们有时候会跟创始人说，"如果你们真要失败的话，至少失败得有点新意，别再用那些我们已经见过一百遍的老套路了。"
text_es: Creo que la realidad es que no somos muy buenos prediciendo qué va a funcionar. Definitivamente no podemos adivinar cuál va a ser la empresa que realmente la va a romper en el grupo. Eso es imposible. En lo que sí somos buenos es en reconocer cómo se ve el fracaso. A veces lo que les decimos a los fundadores al principio es algo así como: "Si van a fracasar, por favor háganlo de alguna manera nueva y emocionante. No de una forma que ya hemos visto cien veces."
context: Lenny asks Gustaf how good Y Combinator is at predicting which startups will become monster hits like Airbnb or Dropbox. Gustaf gives an honest assessment that even with extensive experience working with over 600 companies, predicting massive success is nearly impossible. Instead, YC focuses on helping founders avoid common failure patterns that they've observed repeatedly across many startups.
vocabulary_highlights: monster hits, what failure looks like, in some new exciting way
topics: Starting a Company, Decision Making, Learning & Growth

speaker: Gustaf Alströmer
speaker_expertise: Product Strategy, Growth Strategy, Climate Tech
text: I think when people think about quality, they often think about, 'What is my personal definition of quality?' I have a bar of quality, but quality to me of a good product idea, a good startup idea, has more to do with the customer think is valuable. And if you move fast by talking to customers and having customer learnings and know the problems, then you will actually come up with something that's high quality.
text_ko: 제 생각엔 사람들이 품질을 생각할 때 보통 '내가 생각하는 품질의 정의는 뭘까?' 같은 개인적인 기준을 떠올려요. 하지만 저는 좋은 제품 아이디어(product idea)나 스타트업 아이디어(startup)는 제 기준보다 고객이 가치 있다고 느끼는지가 더 중요하다고 봐요. 고객과 빠르게 대화하고 고객 인사이트(customer learnings)를 얻어 문제를 정확히 알게 되면 오히려 높은 품질의 결과물이 나오거든요.
text_zh: 我觉得大家一提到质量，往往想的是"我个人对质量的定义是什么？"我有自己的质量标准，但对我来说，一个好产品想法、好的创业点子的质量，更多取决于客户觉得有没有价值。如果你通过跟客户聊天、了解客户需求、摸清楚问题在哪儿来快速行动，那你其实就能做出高质量的东西。
text_es: Creo que cuando la gente piensa en calidad, muchas veces se pregunta: "¿Cuál es mi definición personal de calidad?" Yo tengo mi estándar de calidad, pero para mí, la calidad de una buena idea de producto, de una buena idea de startup, tiene más que ver con lo que el cliente considera valioso. Y si te mueves rápido hablando con clientes, aprendiendo de ellos y conociendo bien los problemas, entonces vas a crear algo que realmente tenga calidad.
context: Lenny presents Gustaf with a founder's dilemma about whether to focus on speed versus quality. Gustaf argues that this is a false dichotomy and explains that true quality in startups isn't about the founder's personal standards, but about creating something customers find valuable. He emphasizes that speed in customer discovery actually leads to higher quality products because you understand real problems better.
vocabulary_highlights: bar of quality, false dichotomy, customer learnings
topics: Product Management, Starting a Company, Strategy & Planning

speaker: Gustaf Alströmer
speaker_expertise: Product Strategy, Growth Strategy, Climate Tech
text: I don't think that you can just decide... You can't also be fully collaborative, everyone gets decided about everything. So small startups agree on how they decide together. So after that, everyone just follow the process. That's usually how things work out.
text_ko: 그냥 한 사람이 “결정하면 된다”라고만 할 수는 없다고 생각해요. 반대로 모든 걸 다 같이, 완전 협업으로 모두가 합의해서 결정해야 한다고도 할 수 없고요. 그래서 소규모 스타트업(small startups)들은 누구랑 어떻게 결정을 내릴지 미리 합의해요. 그다음에는 다들 그 프로세스를 따라서 움직이는 경우가 대부분이에요.
text_zh: 我觉得不是说你想怎么决定就怎么决定的...你也不能什么事都让所有人一起商量，每个人对每件事都要参与决策。所以小的创业公司要先商量好大家怎么做决定。定好了之后，大家就按这个流程走。通常都是这么搞的。
text_es: No creo que puedas simplemente decidir... Tampoco puedes ser totalmente colaborativo, que todo el mundo opine sobre cada cosa. Entonces las startups pequeñas se ponen de acuerdo sobre cómo van a tomar decisiones juntos. Y después de eso, todos siguen el proceso. Así es como suelen funcionar las cosas normalmente.
context: Gustaf responds to Lenny's question about whether successful founders tend to be more autocratic (like Steve Jobs) or more collaborative in their leadership style. He explains that for small startups, the key isn't being at either extreme, but rather establishing clear decision-making processes that the founding team agrees on and then consistently following those processes to avoid endless rehashing of decisions.
vocabulary_highlights: fully collaborative, everyone gets decided about everything, rehashing of decisions
topics: Leadership & Management, Starting a Company, Decision Making

speaker: Gustaf Alströmer
speaker_expertise: Product Strategy, Growth Strategy, Climate Tech
text: In that transition, we're talking about trillions of dollars of money moving from things that cause climate change to things that don't. The scale of this transition is not something we've seen recently. Like software is not that big in comparison. It actually is much smaller than this transition.
text_ko: 그 전환(transition)에서는 기후변화(climate change)를 유발하는 쪽에서 그렇지 않은 쪽으로 수조 달러가 이동한다고 얘기하는 거예요. 이 전환의 규모는 최근에 우리가 본 것과는 비교가 안 되는 수준이에요. 소프트웨어(software) 같은 건 이거에 비하면 규모가 작아요. 사실 훨씬 작죠.
text_zh: 在这个转型过程中，我们说的是万亿美元级别的资金要从那些造成气候变化的领域转向不造成气候变化的领域。这个转型的规模是我们最近都没见过的。就连软件行业跟这个比起来都不算什么，实际上比这个转型要小得多。
text_es: En esa transición, estamos hablando de billones de dólares que se van a mover de cosas que causan el cambio climático a cosas que no lo causan. La magnitud de esta transición es algo que no hemos visto en mucho tiempo. O sea, el software no es tan grande en comparación. En realidad es muchísimo más pequeño que esta transición.
context: Gustaf explains why climate tech has become such an attractive area for entrepreneurs and investors. He's describing the massive economic opportunity created by the global transition away from carbon-emitting technologies. This represents a fundamental shift where governments and corporations have committed to changing entire energy systems, creating unprecedented business opportunities that dwarf even the software industry in scale.
vocabulary_highlights: trillions of dollars, dwarf even the software industry, unprecedented business opportunities
topics: Starting a Company, Strategy & Planning, Growth & Marketing

speaker: Gustav Söderström
speaker_expertise: Product Strategy, User Experience, Engineering Leadership
text: I suspect it will be as big of a shift that you will eventually have to rethink your products. We have to rethink the user interface and the experience for recommendation first era. And so what does that mean in the generative era? No one really knows yet.
text_ko: 이건 결국 제품을 다시 생각해봐야 할 만큼 큰 변화가 될 것 같아요. 먼저 추천 우선 시대(recommendation-first era)의 사용자 인터페이스(user interface)와 사용자 경험(user experience)을 다시 생각해야 해요. 그렇다면 생성 시대(generative era)에서는 그게 어떤 의미일까요? 사실 아직 아무도 잘 모르겠어요.
text_zh: 我觉得这个转变会很大，大到你最终得重新思考自己的产品。我们必须重新考虑用户界面和体验，因为我们现在进入了推荐优先的时代。那么在生成式AI(generative)时代这意味着什么呢？说实话，现在还没人真正搞清楚。
text_es: Me parece que va a ser un cambio tan grande que al final van a tener que replantearse sus productos. Nosotros tenemos que repensar la interfaz de usuario y la experiencia para esta era donde las recomendaciones son lo primero. ¿Y qué significa eso en la era generativa? La verdad es que nadie lo sabe todavía.
context: Lenny asks Gustav about how product teams should think about AI in their product thinking. Gustav explains his framework for understanding the evolution of the internet in three stages: curation (where users manually organize content), recommendation (where algorithms do this work), and now generation (where AI creates content). He emphasizes that each transition required companies to completely rethink their user experience and business models, and believes the shift to generative AI will be equally transformative.
vocabulary_highlights: as big of a shift, rethink your products, recommendation first era, generative era

speaker: Gustav Söderström
speaker_expertise: Product Strategy, User Experience, Engineering Leadership
text: So that product couldn't have existed without generative AI, both generating the voice and generating the content of what the voice says. So you can have individualized, personalized voice at the scale of half a billion people.
text_ko: 그 제품은 생성형 AI (generative AI)가 없었다면 아예 존재할 수 없었어요. 목소리를 만들어내는 것부터 그 목소리가 말하는 내용을 생성하는 것까지 모두 생성형 AI 덕분이었거든요. 그래서 5억 명 규모로 개인별 맞춤 음성을 제공할 수 있어요.
text_zh: 所以这个产品离不开生成式AI(generative AI)，既要生成语音，又要生成语音说的内容。这样你就能做到个性化的语音服务，而且能覆盖到五亿人的规模。
text_es: Ese producto no habría podido existir sin IA generativa, tanto para generar la voz como para crear el contenido de lo que dice esa voz. Así puedes tener una voz individualizada y personalizada a escala de quinientos millones de personas.
context: Gustav discusses Spotify's AI DJ feature as their first true generative AI product. The AI DJ is a digitized version of a real person named X who talks to users about music they like and suggests new tracks. Gustav explains this represents a new category of product that literally couldn't exist without generative AI technology, as it requires both voice generation and content generation to provide personalized commentary at massive scale.
vocabulary_highlights: couldn't have existed without, individualized, personalized, at the scale of

speaker: Gustav Söderström
speaker_expertise: Product Strategy, User Experience, Engineering Leadership
text: The principle of fault-tolerant user interfaces. So you need to understand the performance of your machine learning to design for it. The quality of your machine learning, if you're going to have a single play button, needs to be literally 100% or zero prediction error, and that's never the case.
text_ko: 이건 결함 허용 사용자 인터페이스(fault-tolerant user interfaces)의 원칙이에요. 그래서 설계할 때는 머신러닝(machine learning)이 실제로 어느 정도 성능을 내는지 정확히 이해해야 해요. 재생 버튼 하나로 모든 걸 처리하려면 그 머신러닝의 품질은 문자 그대로 100% 정확하거나 예측 오류가 전혀 없어야 하는데, 현실에서는 그런 경우가 절대 없어요.
text_zh: 容错用户界面(fault-tolerant user interfaces)的原理。所以你得先搞清楚你的机器学习模型表现怎么样，然后针对性地去设计。如果你想做那种一键播放的功能，你的机器学习质量就得做到百分之百准确，预测错误率为零才行，但现实中根本不可能做到这一点。
text_es: El principio de interfaces tolerantes a fallos (fault-tolerant). O sea, tienes que entender cómo se comporta tu machine learning para poder diseñar en base a eso. La calidad de tu machine learning, si vas a tener un solo botón de reproducir, tiene que ser literalmente del 100% o cero error de predicción, y eso nunca pasa.
context: Gustav shares key principles for building AI-powered products, crediting Chris Dixon for this concept. He explains that UI design must account for the imperfection of machine learning algorithms. Gustav uses the example that if your algorithm has a one-in-five hit rate, you need to show at least five options on screen so users have a good chance of finding something relevant, rather than designing a single play button that would disappoint users 80% of the time.
vocabulary_highlights: fault-tolerant user interfaces, zero prediction error, literally 100%, that's never the case

speaker: Gustav Söderström
speaker_expertise: Product Strategy, User Experience, Engineering Leadership
text: So if you're hiring smart people, one way to think about it is you're renting brain power. So if you're renting all of this expensive brain power and then you give them no room to think for themselves, that doesn't sound smart, then you should actually hire less smart people and keep your costs down or something.
text_ko: 똑똑한 사람을 뽑는다고 하면, 한 가지로 생각해볼 수 있는 건 그 사람들의 두뇌 역량(brain power)을 빌리는 셈이라는 거예요. 비싼 두뇌 역량을 빌려놓고도 그들에게 스스로 생각할 여지를 전혀 주지 않으면, 그건 현명한 선택이 아니에요. 그런 상황이라면 차라리 덜 똑똑한 사람을 뽑아서 비용을 낮추는 게 낫겠죠.
text_zh: 如果你要招聪明人，可以这么想，你其实是在租用脑力。既然你花大价钱租了这些厉害的脑子，结果又不给人家独立思考的空间，这不是很傻嘛？那还不如直接招些普通点的人，还能省钱呢。
text_es: Entonces, si estás contratando gente inteligente, una forma de verlo es que estás alquilando capacidad intelectual. O sea, si estás alquilando toda esta capacidad intelectual tan cara y después no les das espacio para que piensen por sí mismos, eso no suena muy inteligente. Mejor contrata gente menos capacitada y mantén los costos bajos o algo así.
context: Gustav explains why Spotify moved away from their famous squad model and how they now think about organizational autonomy. He discusses the balance between giving employees autonomy to maximize their talent versus maintaining strategic alignment. Gustav argues that if you're paying high salaries for smart people, you need to give them space to think and contribute meaningfully, otherwise you're wasting your investment in talent.
vocabulary_highlights: you're renting brain power, keep your costs down, doesn't sound smart

speaker: Gustav Söderström
speaker_expertise: Product Strategy, User Experience, Engineering Leadership
text: But the problem with that is if you put autonomy very far towards the leaves of the organization, and also if you combine that with having a very junior organization, which we did back then, there's a fair chance that you're just going to produce heat. You're going to have a hundred squads with a hundred strategies running in a hundred directions.
text_ko: 문제는 자율성(autonomy)을 조직의 말단까지 너무 많이 맡기고, 거기에 우리가 그때 그랬던 것처럼 경험이 적은 주니어 조직(junior organization)이 겹치면 결국 그냥 에너지(heat)만 낭비할 가능성이 크다는 거예요. 스쿼드(squad) 백 개가 각각 다른 전략으로 제각각 움직이게 될 테니까요.
text_zh: 但问题在于，如果你把自主权完全下放到组织的最底层，再加上当时我们团队都比较年轻缺乏经验，很可能就是瞎忙活一通。最后搞出一百个小团队，一百套策略，往一百个不同方向跑。
text_es: Pero el problema con eso es que si das mucha autonomía a los niveles más bajos de la organización, y además lo combinas con tener un equipo muy junior, como teníamos en ese entonces, hay muchas posibilidades de que solo generes caos. Vas a terminar con cien equipos con cien estrategias distintas yendo cada uno por su lado.
context: Gustav continues explaining why Spotify's original squad model became problematic as they scaled. He describes how giving too much autonomy to junior employees at the bottom of the organization ("the leaves") combined with their young, inexperienced workforce led to inefficiency. The metaphor of "producing heat" refers to wasted energy - lots of activity but not productive work aligned toward common goals.
vocabulary_highlights: towards the leaves of the organization, produce heat, running in a hundred directions

speaker: Gustav Söderström
speaker_expertise: Product Strategy, User Experience, Engineering Leadership
text: What we misjudged or failed or rather learned about our own homepage is that the way it works right now, if you look at what people do on Spotify's homepage, the current one, it is almost 90% what we call recall. So it is either getting to a session that you're already in or a specific playlist that you know you want to get to or at least a specific use case.
text_ko: 우리가 우리 홈페이지에 대해 잘못 판단했다기보다는 오히려 배운 건, 지금의 작동 방식이—스포티파이의 현재 홈페이지에서 사람들이 뭘 하는지 보면—거의 90%가 우리가 '리콜(recall)'이라고 부르는 유형이라는 거예요. 즉 이미 들어가 있는 세션(session)으로 이동하거나, 가려는 특정 플레이리스트(playlist)로 바로 가거나, 최소한 특정 사용 사례(use case)에 해당하는 행동인 셈이에요.
text_zh: 我们对自己主页的误判，或者说失误，或者更准确地说我们学到的是，现在这个主页的运作方式，如果你看看用户在Spotify主页上都干什么，现有的这个主页，基本上90%都是我们说的recall（回想召回）。就是说要么是回到你已经在听的那个session（播放会话），要么是找你知道想听的某个特定播放列表，或者至少是某个特定的使用场景。
text_es: Lo que calculamos mal o más bien aprendimos sobre nuestra página de inicio es que tal como funciona ahora, si te fijas en lo que hace la gente en la homepage de Spotify, la actual, es casi un 90% lo que llamamos recall. O sea, es llegar a una sesión en la que ya estás o a una playlist específica que sabes que quieres escuchar, o por lo menos a un caso de uso específico.
context: Gustav shares lessons from Spotify's recent homepage redesign that received negative user feedback. He explains they discovered that 90% of homepage usage is "recall" - users coming to find specific content they already know they want, like returning to a playlist or resuming a session. Only 10% is true discovery of new content. When they redesigned to prioritize discovery, they flipped this ratio and users couldn't easily find their familiar content anymore.
vocabulary_highlights: what we misjudged, what we call recall, specific use case

speaker: Gustav Söderström
speaker_expertise: Product Strategy, User Experience, Engineering Leadership
text: I think there are two fundamentally different types of product development. One is designing a new feature. It is hard, but it's voluntary for people to use. But when you redesign, it is much more tricky because it's not voluntary to participate in the redesign. So there's a cost even for people who don't like it.
text_ko: 저는 제품 개발(product development)이 근본적으로 두 가지 종류가 있다고 생각해요. 하나는 새로운 기능(feature)을 설계하는 건데, 어렵긴 해도 사람들이 쓰는 건 자발적인 선택이에요. 반면 리디자인(redesign)은 훨씬 더 까다로워요. 리디자인엔 참여가 자발적이지 않아서, 싫어하는 사람들에게도 비용(cost)이 발생하거든요.
text_zh: 我觉得产品开发基本上分两种。一种是做新功能，虽然难搞，但用户愿意用就用，不愿意用就算了。但重新设计就麻烦多了，因为用户没得选择，必须接受这个改版。所以哪怕有人不喜欢，他们也得承担这个成本。
text_es: Creo que hay dos tipos de desarrollo de producto completamente diferentes. Uno es diseñar una nueva funcionalidad. Es difícil, pero la gente puede elegir si la usa o no. Pero cuando rediseñas, es mucho más complicado porque no es opcional participar en el rediseño. Entonces hay un costo incluso para la gente a la que no le gusta.
context: Gustav reflects on the challenges of redesigning existing products versus building new features. He explains that new features are optional - if users don't like them, they simply don't use them. However, redesigns force all users to adapt to changes, creating unavoidable costs even for users who preferred the old version. This fundamental difference makes redesigns much riskier and more complex from a product development perspective.
vocabulary_highlights: fundamentally different types, it's not voluntary, there's a cost even for

speaker: Hamel Husain
speaker_expertise: AI/ML Products, Data Analytics, Product Management
text: Sure. Evals is a way to systematically measure and improve an AI application, and it really doesn't have to be scary or unapproachable at all. It really is, at its core, data analytics on your LLM application and a systematic way of looking at that data, and where necessary, creating metrics around things so you can measure what's happening, and then so you can iterate and do experiments and improve.
text_ko: 물론이죠. Evals는 AI 애플리케이션을 체계적으로 측정하고 개선하는 방법이에요. 전혀 무섭거나 접근하기 어려운 게 아니에요. 본질적으로는 대형 언어 모델(LLM) 애플리케이션에 대한 데이터 분석(data analytics)이고, 그 데이터를 체계적으로 바라보는 방식이에요. 필요할 때는 무슨 일이 일어나고 있는지 측정할 수 있도록 지표(metrics)를 만들고, 그걸 바탕으로 반복해서 실험하고 개선해 나가면 되는 거예요.
text_zh: 当然。评估(Evals)其实就是系统性地衡量和改进AI应用的一种方法，真的没什么可怕的，也不是什么高深莫测的东西。说白了，核心就是对你的大语言模型(LLM)应用做数据分析，系统性地看这些数据，必要的时候给一些指标量化一下，这样你就能知道到底发生了什么，然后就可以不断迭代、做实验、持续改进。
text_es: Claro. Los evals son una forma sistemática de medir y mejorar una aplicación de IA, y la verdad es que no tiene por qué dar miedo ni ser algo inalcanzable. En el fondo, es análisis de datos de tu aplicación LLM y una manera sistemática de revisar esa información, y cuando sea necesario, crear métricas para poder medir lo que está pasando, y así poder iterar, hacer experimentos y mejorar.
context: Lenny asks Hamel to explain what evals are for people who have never heard the term. Hamel provides a foundational definition, emphasizing that evals are not mysterious or complex but simply a systematic approach to measuring and improving AI applications through data analysis.
vocabulary_highlights: systematically measure, unapproachable, at its core

speaker: Hamel Husain
speaker_expertise: AI/ML Products, Data Analytics, Product Management
text: When you're doing this open coding, a lot of teams get bogged down in having a committee do this. For a lot of situations, that's wholly unnecessary. You don't want to make this process so expensive that you can't do it. You can appoint one person whose taste that you trust. It should be the person with domain expertise. Oftentimes, it is the product manager.
text_ko: 오픈 코딩(open coding)을 할 때 많은 팀이 이걸 위원회에 맡기느라 일이 지체돼요. 많은 경우 그건 전혀 필요하지 않아요. 이 과정을 너무 비용이 많이 들게 만들어 실행 자체가 불가능해지면 안 돼요. 판단력이 믿을 만한 한 사람을 지정하면 돼요. 그 사람은 도메인 전문성(domain expertise)이 있는 사람이어야 해요. 보통 제품 매니저(product manager)가 그 역할을 맡아요.
text_zh: 做开放式编码(open coding)的时候，很多团队都会陷入委员会决策的泥潭。其实大部分情况下，这完全没必要。你不能让这个流程变得成本太高，搞得做都做不起。你可以指定一个你信得过、有判断力的人来负责。最好是在这个领域有专业知识的人。通常来说，就是产品经理最合适。
text_es: Cuando estás haciendo esta codificación abierta (open coding), muchos equipos se atascan tratando de que lo haga un comité entero. Para la mayoría de situaciones, eso no tiene ningún sentido. No quieres que este proceso sea tan caro que al final no lo puedas hacer. Puedes asignar a una sola persona en la que confíes, alguien que tenga buen criterio. Debería ser la persona que más conoce del tema. Muchas veces es el product manager.
context: Lenny asks about the concept of a 'benevolent dictator' in the evals process. Hamel explains that when doing open coding (manually reviewing and categorizing AI application errors), teams often get stuck trying to involve everyone in the decision-making process, which slows things down unnecessarily.
vocabulary_highlights: get bogged down, wholly unnecessary, whose taste that you trust

speaker: Hamel Husain
speaker_expertise: AI/ML Products, Data Analytics, Product Management
text: Everyone that does this immediately gets addicted to it. When you're building an AI application, you just learn a lot and you're like, 'Hmm, this is not how I want it to work. Okay.' And so that's just an example.
text_ko: 한번 해보면 다들 바로 빠져들어요. AI 애플리케이션(AI application)을 만들다 보면 배우는 게 엄청 많아서 '음, 이건 내가 원하던 대로 작동하지 않네. 알겠어요.' 하고 생각하게 돼요. 그러니까 그건 그냥 하나의 예일 뿐이에요.
text_zh: 每个人一接触这个就上瘾了。你在搭建AI应用的时候，会学到很多东西，然后就会想"嗯，这不是我想要的效果，好吧。"这就是个典型的例子。
text_es: Todos los que hacen esto se enganchan de inmediato. Cuando estás desarrollando una aplicación de IA, simplemente aprendes un montón y te quedas como "Mmm, esto no es como quiero que funcione. Ok." Y bueno, ese es solo un ejemplo.
context: Hamel is explaining the process of manually reviewing AI application traces (logs of user interactions) to identify errors. He's describing how product teams react when they start systematically looking at how their AI applications are actually performing in real conversations with users.
vocabulary_highlights: gets addicted to it

speaker: Shreya Shankar
speaker_expertise: AI/ML Products, Data Analytics, Product Management
text: One common question that we get from people at this stage is, 'Okay, I understand what's going on. Can I ask an LLM to do this process for me?' And I loved Hamel's most recent example because what we usually find when we try to ask an LLM to do this error analysis is it just says the trace looks good because it doesn't have the context needed to understand whether something might be bad product smell or not.
text_ko: 이 단계에 있는 분들한테 자주 받는 질문 중 하나가, "알겠어요, 무슨 일이 일어나고 있는지는 이해했어요. 이 과정을 대형 언어 모델(LLM)에게 시켜도 될까요?"예요. 해멜의 최근 예시가 참 마음에 들었던 이유는, 우리가 보통 LLM에게 이런 오류 분석(error analysis)을 부탁해 보면 LLM은 필요한 맥락(context)이 없어서 그냥 트레이스(trace)가 괜찮아 보인다고만 하고, 그게 제품 이상 징후(product smell)에 해당하는지 판단하진 못하더라는 거예요.
text_zh: 在这个阶段，大家经常会问我们："好吧，我明白是怎么回事了。那我能不能直接让LLM帮我做这个流程？" 我特别喜欢Hamel最近举的那个例子，因为通常我们试图让LLM做错误分析(error analysis)的时候，它就会说追踪记录(trace)看起来没问题，因为它根本没有足够的上下文来判断某些东西是不是有问题的产品征象(product smell)。
text_es: Una pregunta muy común que nos hacen las personas en esta etapa es: 'Vale, ya entiendo lo que está pasando. ¿Puedo pedirle a un LLM que haga este proceso por mí?' Y me encantó el último ejemplo de Hamel porque lo que normalmente encontramos cuando tratamos de pedirle a un LLM que haga este análisis de errores es que simplemente dice que el trace se ve bien, porque no tiene el contexto necesario para entender si algo podría ser una mala señal del producto (bad product smell) o no.
context: Shreya is explaining why humans need to do the initial error analysis rather than automating it with AI. She's responding to a common misconception that LLMs can automatically identify problems in AI application traces without human domain expertise and product context.
vocabulary_highlights: bad product smell

speaker: Shreya Shankar
speaker_expertise: AI/ML Products, Data Analytics, Product Management
text: The goal is not to do evals perfectly, it's to actionably improve your product. We guarantee you, no matter what you do, if you're doing parts of these process, you're going to find ways of actionable improvement, and then you're going to iterate on your own process from there.
text_ko: 목표는 평가(evals)를 완벽하게 하는 게 아니라 제품을 실제로 개선(actionably improve)하는 거예요. 장담해요 — 뭐를 하든 이 프로세스(process)의 일부라도 하고 있다면 실질적으로 개선할 방법(actionable improvement)을 꼭 찾게 되고, 그걸 바탕으로 자체 프로세스를 계속 반복(iterate)해서 개선해 나가게 될 거예요.
text_zh: 目标不是把评估做得十全十美，而是要能实实在在地改进你的产品。我们敢保证，不管你怎么做，只要你把这些流程的一部分做起来，你肯定能找到切实可行的改进方法，然后在这个基础上不断优化你自己的流程。
text_es: El objetivo no es hacer las evaluaciones de manera perfecta, sino mejorar tu producto de forma práctica. Te garantizamos que sin importar lo que hagas, si estás aplicando partes de este proceso, vas a encontrar maneras concretas de mejorar, y de ahí vas a ir ajustando tu propio proceso sobre la marcha.
context: Shreya is giving advice to people who feel intimidated about starting the evals process. She's addressing the common concern that people need to execute evals flawlessly, emphasizing that the primary objective is product improvement rather than perfect execution of the evaluation methodology.
vocabulary_highlights: actionably improve, actionable improvement

speaker: Shreya Shankar
speaker_expertise: AI/ML Products, Data Analytics, Product Management
text: People have been burned by evals in the past. People have done evals badly, so then they didn't trust it anymore, and then they're like, 'Oh, I'm anti evals.' I 100% empathize with that, because you should be anti Likert scale LLM judge.
text_ko: 사람들이 과거에 평가(evals) 때문에 피해를 본 적이 있어요. 평가를 엉망으로 해서 신뢰를 잃었고, 그래서 '난 평가 반대야'라고 하는 사람이 나온 거예요. 저도 그 마음을 100% 공감해요. 리커트 척도(Likert scale) 기반 LLM 판정(LLM judge)에는 반대하는 게 맞아요.
text_zh: 很多人以前在评估(evals)上吃过亏。有些人把评估搞砸了，结果就不再相信这套东西，然后就说"我就是反对评估"。我完全理解这种想法，因为你确实应该反对那种李克特量表LLM判断(Likert scale LLM judge)的方式。
text_es: La gente ha tenido malas experiencias con las evaluaciones antes. Han hecho evaluaciones muy mal, entonces ya no confían en ellas, y dicen "Ay no, yo estoy en contra de las evaluaciones."
