Entiendo perfectamente esa postura, porque deberías estar en contra de los jueces LLM con escala Likert (Likert scale LLM judge).
context: Lenny asks about the controversy and debate around evals in the AI community. Shreya explains why some people are skeptical of evals, noting that many have had bad experiences with poorly implemented evaluation systems. A Likert scale LLM judge refers to using AI to score outputs on a 1-5 or 1-7 rating scale rather than binary pass/fail judgments.
vocabulary_highlights: have been burned by, anti Likert scale

speaker: Hamilton Helmer
speaker_expertise: Company Building, Growth Strategy, Product Management
text: One of the things that has really surprised me in the last five years has been that my understanding of the answer to that question has changed. And before I thought it was you do product market fit and then you do strategy, and if you try and put strategy before product market fit, it is not much you can do with it. That's wrong.
text_ko: 지난 5년 동안 저를 정말 놀라게 한 것 중 하나는 그 질문에 대한 제 생각이 달라졌다는 거예요. 예전에는 먼저 제품-시장 적합성(product market fit)을 맞추고 그다음에 전략(strategy)을 세우는 거라고 생각했어요. 전략을 제품-시장 적합성보다 먼저 놓으면 그 전략으로 할 수 있는 게 별로 없을 거라고 생각했죠. 그런데 그건 틀렸어요.
text_zh: 这五年来最让我意外的一点就是，我对这个问题的理解完全变了。以前我觉得应该是先做产品市场匹配(product market fit)，然后再做战略，如果你想在产品市场匹配之前就搞战略的话，基本上没什么用。这种想法是错的。
text_es: Una de las cosas que realmente me ha sorprendido en estos últimos cinco años es que mi forma de entender la respuesta a esa pregunta ha cambiado completamente. Antes pensaba que primero tenías que lograr el product market fit y después hacer estrategia, y que si intentabas poner la estrategia antes del product market fit, pues no podías hacer mucho con eso. Estaba equivocado.
context: Lenny asks Hamilton when founders should start thinking about power - before or after achieving product-market fit. Hamilton explains that his thinking has evolved over the past five years based on conversations with company founders. He used to believe you should focus on product-market fit first, then strategy second, but now realizes this approach is incorrect.
vocabulary_highlights: put strategy before, not much you can do with it

speaker: Hamilton Helmer
speaker_expertise: Company Building, Growth Strategy, Product Management
text: At the earlier stage, you can imagine wildly more degrees of freedom and the questions are of the business propositions that you're thinking of in trying to get to product-market fit, what are the underlying characteristics that might tilt them towards the availability of power or not?
text_ko: 초기 단계에서는 자유도(degrees of freedom)가 훨씬 더 많다고 상상할 수 있어요. 제품-시장 적합성(product-market fit)을 맞추려고 고민할 때, 핵심 질문은 여러분이 생각하는 비즈니스 제안들이 전력 가용성(availability of power)이 있느냐 없느냐에 따라 유리해지거나 불리해지게 만드는 근본적 특성들이 무엇인지예요.
text_zh: 在早期阶段，你可以天马行空地想象更多的可能性，关键问题是你在考虑的商业模式能不能找到产品市场契合度(product-market fit)，这些模式的底层特征会不会让你更容易获得话语权？
text_es: En las etapas tempranas, puedes imaginar muchísimos más grados de libertad y las preguntas van sobre las propuestas de negocio en las que estás pensando para lograr el product-market fit: ¿cuáles son las características de fondo que podrían inclinarlas hacia tener poder de mercado o no?
context: Hamilton continues explaining why early-stage founders should think about strategy even before achieving product-market fit. He clarifies that early-stage strategy isn't about detailed competitive planning, but rather evaluating which business propositions have characteristics that could lead to power (sustainable competitive advantage) later on.
vocabulary_highlights: wildly more degrees of freedom, tilt them towards, availability of power

speaker: Hamilton Helmer
speaker_expertise: Company Building, Growth Strategy, Product Management
text: As I said, I'm a concept person and so when you develop concepts, you have to be very highly constrained by their usefulness. I'm a great fan of the great mathematician, John von Neumann, and he had a view which really irritated a lot of mathematicians, which is that if mathematics wasn't guided by what was useful, it would become, I think the word he used was aesthetic to aesthetic.
text_ko: 말했듯이 저는 개념 중심 사람이에요. 그래서 개념을 개발할 때는 그 유용성에 의해 아주 엄격하게 제약돼야 해요. 저는 위대한 수학자 존 폰 노이만(John von Neumann)을 매우 존경하는데, 그가 가진 생각 중 하나는 많은 수학자들을 불편하게 만들었어요. 그는 수학이 쓸모 있는 것에 의해 이끌리지 않으면, 결국 ‘미학을 위한 미학’(aesthetic to aesthetic)으로 흘러간다고 봤어요.
text_zh: 就像我说的，我是个搞概念的人，所以当你在开发概念的时候，必须要严格考虑它们的实用性。我特别推崇伟大的数学家冯·诺伊曼，他有个观点让很多数学家都不爽，就是说如果数学不以实用为导向的话，就会变成纯粹为了美感而美感的东西。
text_es: Como te dije, soy una persona de conceptos, y cuando desarrollas conceptos, tienes que estar muy limitado por su utilidad práctica. Soy gran admirador del matemático John von Neumann, y él tenía una perspectiva que realmente molestaba a muchos matemáticos: que si las matemáticas no se guiaban por lo que era útil, se volverían, creo que la palabra que usaba era "estética por estética" (aesthetic to aesthetic).
context: Lenny asks Hamilton to define strategy and explain how it relates to power. Hamilton begins by explaining his philosophy on developing business concepts - they must be constrained by their practical usefulness. He references mathematician John von Neumann's controversial view that mathematics should be guided by utility rather than pure aesthetics.
vocabulary_highlights: concept person, highly constrained by their usefulness, aesthetic to aesthetic

speaker: Hamilton Helmer
speaker_expertise: Company Building, Growth Strategy, Product Management
text: So think of Pearl Harbor, Pearl Harbor for the Japanese was this enormous tactical success. They just destroyed the US ability, naval ability in the Pacific Ocean and the worst possible strategic move because it completely solved Franklin Delano Roosevelt's problem of how he could get the US citizens on board to attacking Hitler.
text_ko: 그러니까 진주만을 떠올려 보세요. 일본 입장에선 진주만 공격이 전술적으로는 엄청난 성공이었어요. 태평양에서 미국의 해군력을 완전히 무력화시켰죠. 그런데 전략적으로는 최악의 실수였어요. 그 공격이 프랭클린 D. 루스벨트가 미국 국민들을 히틀러 공격에 찬성하도록 만들 방법을 완전히 해결해 줬거든요.
text_zh: 你想想珍珠港事件，对日本人来说，这在战术上是个巨大的成功。他们直接把美国在太平洋的海军力量给摧毁了，但从战略角度来看，这是最愚蠢的一步棋，因为这完全帮罗斯福总统解决了一个大难题——怎么让美国老百姓支持去打希特勒。
text_es: Piensen en Pearl Harbor, Pearl Harbor para los japoneses fue un éxito táctico tremendo. Acabaron con la capacidad naval de Estados Unidos en el Pacífico, pero fue la peor jugada estratégica posible porque le resolvió completamente el problema a Franklin Delano Roosevelt de cómo convencer a los ciudadanos estadounidenses de ir a la guerra contra Hitler.
context: Hamilton is explaining why strategy should focus on long-term business value creation, which requires thinking far into the future. He uses Pearl Harbor as a historical example to illustrate the critical difference between tactical success (short-term wins) and strategic thinking (long-term consequences). The attack was tactically successful but strategically disastrous for Japan.
vocabulary_highlights: enormous tactical success, worst possible strategic move, get the US citizens on board

speaker: Hamilton Helmer
speaker_expertise: Company Building, Growth Strategy, Product Management
text: So take branding and process power and process power is really operational excellence on steroids and usually is imitable, so it's usually not. So take those off the table and then a resource type of power, which is you have something that is of value that if you transferred it to somebody else it would be of value to them, but you own the rights.
text_ko: 그러니까 브랜딩(branding)과 프로세스 파워(process power)를 빼보면, 프로세스 파워는 사실 운영 우수성(operational excellence)을 극단적으로 강화한 거고 보통은 모방당하기 쉬워서 지속적인 우위가 되기 어렵요. 그런 것들을 제외하면 자원형 파워(resource-type power)가 남는데, 그건 다른 사람에게 이전해줘도 그 사람에게 가치가 되는 무언가를 당신이 가지고 있고 그에 대한 권리를 소유하고 있다는 뜻이에요.
text_zh: 所以说品牌和流程优势就先不谈了，流程优势其实就是运营卓越(operational excellence)的加强版，通常都是可以被复制的，所以基本上不算什么护城河。把这些都排除掉之后，还有一种叫资源型优势，就是你手里有些值钱的东西，这些东西如果给别人用也很有价值，但是使用权在你手上。
text_es: Entonces quítale el branding y el poder de procesos, y el poder de procesos en realidad es excelencia operacional pero potenciada al máximo, y normalmente se puede imitar, o sea, por lo general no es exclusivo. Entonces descarta esos y luego tienes el poder de recursos (resource power), que es cuando tienes algo valioso que si se lo pasaras a otra persona también le sería valioso, pero tú tienes los derechos.
context: Lenny asks Hamilton which of the seven powers are most relevant for early-stage startups. Hamilton explains that startups should focus on only four of the seven powers because three are typically unavailable to them. He's defining which powers to 'take off the table' - branding, process power, and resource power are generally not accessible to early-stage companies.
vocabulary_highlights: operational excellence on steroids, take those off the table, own the rights

speaker: Hamilton Helmer
speaker_expertise: Company Building, Growth Strategy, Product Management
text: We laugh whenever we hear somebody say they have a flywheel, which gives you the idea of network economies. There are often flywheels, the ones that really are material, are rare. The key thing here is materiality, not whether the flywheel exists, but whether the effect is strong enough to really tilt returns.
text_ko: 누군가 '플라이휠(flywheel)이 있어요'라고 하면 늘 웃게 돼요. 그 말이 네트워크 경제(network economies)를 떠올리게 하거든요. 플라이휠이라고 주장하는 경우는 많지만, 실제로 실질성(materiality)이 있는 플라이휠은 드물어요. 여기서 중요한 건 플라이휠의 존재 여부가 아니라 그 실질성(materiality), 즉 효과가 실제로 수익률을 확실히 기울일 만큼 충분히 강한지 여부예요.
text_zh: 每次听到有人说他们有飞轮效应(flywheel)、有网络经济效应什么的，我们就想笑。飞轮这东西到处都有，但真正管用的很少见。关键不在于你有没有飞轮，而在于这个效应够不够强，能不能真正带来实质性的回报提升。
text_es: Nos reímos cada vez que escuchamos a alguien decir que tiene un flywheel, que te da la idea de economías de red. A menudo hay flywheels, pero los que realmente son importantes son escasos. Lo clave aquí es qué tan significativo es, no si el flywheel existe, sino si el efecto es lo suficientemente fuerte como para realmente inclinar los rendimientos.
context: Lenny asks Hamilton about common misconceptions founders have about their competitive advantages. Hamilton is discussing how founders often incorrectly claim they have powerful 'flywheels' (self-reinforcing business cycles that create network effects). He explains that while many businesses have some flywheel effects, very few have effects strong enough to materially impact their financial performance.
vocabulary_highlights: really are material, strong enough to really tilt returns

speaker: Hamilton Helmer
speaker_expertise: Company Building, Growth Strategy, Product Management
text: And so all that thoughtfulness about which things you put first and how you structure it and all that to make this suitable was mimicable. So that's an understanding of looking at the properties you have and trying to figure out if they're a castle or a shack.
text_ko: 그래서 무엇을 우선으로 두고 어떻게 구조화할지, 즉 적절하게 만들기 위해 신경 쓴 부분들은 모방할 수 있었어요(mimicable). 결국 그건 자신이 가진 특성(properties)을 보고 그게 성(castle)인지 오두막(shack)인지 가늠해 보려는 이해예요.
text_zh: 所以说，你在考虑什么东西放在前面、怎么去架构整个结构，怎么让它变得合适——这些用心的地方其实都是可以学习和模仿的。换句话说，就是要看清楚你手里的资产到底是什么性质的，搞明白它们到底是城堡还是破房子。
text_es: Y entonces toda esa reflexión sobre qué cosas pones primero y cómo lo estructuras y todo eso para que fuera replicable, eso se podía imitar. O sea, es entender qué propiedades tienes y tratar de determinar si son un castillo o una choza.
context: Hamilton is explaining Warren Buffett's famous quote about looking for 'economic castles protected by unbreachable moats.' Using Netflix as an example, Hamilton describes how many important business capabilities (like UI development and recommendation engines) can be copied by competitors, making them 'shacks' rather than 'castles' in terms of sustainable competitive advantage.
vocabulary_highlights: was mimicable, if they're a castle or a shack

speaker: Hari Srinivasan
text: You'd think the marketplace would balance pretty quickly. You'd think, okay, maybe these people will start moving to other jobs, but it wasn't happening. A large reason behind this, people are used to looking for certain particular titles, and they didn't start realizing other people could do this job.
text_ko: 사람들은 보통 시장(marketplace)이 금방 균형을 맞출 거라고 생각해요. '아마 사람들이 다른 직무로 옮기겠지'라고들 예상하지만, 실제로는 그렇지 않았어요. 큰 이유 중 하나는 사람들이 특정 직함(title)만 찾아보는 데 익숙해서 다른 사람이 그 일을 할 수 있다는 걸 잘 인식하지 못했기 때문이에요.
text_zh: 你会觉得市场应该很快就能平衡了，对吧？你会想，好吧，也许这些人会开始跳槽去别的工作，但实际上并没有发生。这背后很大一个原因是，大家都习惯了盯着某些特定的职位头衔，没有意识到其实别人也能干这个活儿。
text_es: Uno pensaría que el mercado se equilibraría bastante rápido. Pensarías, bueno, tal vez esta gente empezaría a moverse a otros trabajos, pero no estaba pasando. Una gran razón detrás de esto es que la gente está acostumbrada a buscar ciertos títulos específicos, y no se dieron cuenta de que otras personas podían hacer ese trabajo.
context: Lenny asks Hari what changes he's seeing in the hiring market. Hari is describing the situation during COVID when hospitality workers were losing jobs while customer service couldn't hire enough people. Despite the obvious mismatch, the marketplace wasn't self-correcting because people were too focused on job titles rather than transferable skills.
vocabulary_highlights: balance pretty quickly, didn't start realizing

speaker: Hari Srinivasan
text: We made a pretty big push in something we call skills-first hiring. This was the idea that we could translate people's experiences into a set of skills, and by that we could help them really start balancing the marketplace with a much different system.
text_ko: 우리는 '역량 중심 채용 (skills-first hiring)'을 적극적으로 추진했어요. 사람들의 경험을 스킬 세트(skill set)로 환산해서, 그렇게 해서 전혀 다른 방식의 시스템으로 인재 시장(marketplace)의 균형을 맞추는 데 실제로 도움이 될 수 있다는 생각이었어요.
text_zh: 我们在技能优先招聘(skills-first hiring)这块下了很大功夫。就是说我们能把人的经历转化成一套技能体系，这样就能帮他们用一套完全不同的系统来平衡市场。
text_es: Hicimos una apuesta bastante fuerte en algo que llamamos contratación basada en habilidades (skills-first hiring). La idea era que podíamos convertir las experiencias de la gente en un conjunto de competencias, y así ayudarles a equilibrar realmente el mercado laboral con un sistema completamente diferente.
context: Hari continues explaining LinkedIn's response to the COVID hiring crisis. Skills-first hiring is LinkedIn's approach where they translate people's work experiences into transferable skills rather than focusing on specific job titles. This allows workers to be matched with roles they might not have considered but have the necessary skills for.
vocabulary_highlights: made a pretty big push, translate people's experiences, balancing the marketplace

speaker: Hari Srinivasan
text: I think that the job market is rebalancing, but it's being done, the pathways are being done in a very different way that seems to be maybe a change that holds through these ups and downs. That'll be very interesting to see.
text_ko: 고용 시장이 재균형을 찾아가는 것 같아요. 그런데 그 과정이나 경로가 훨씬 다른 방식으로 움직이고 있어서, 이런 변화가 경기의 오르내림을 겪어도 계속 유지될 변화인 것 같아요. 그게 어떻게 전개될지 지켜보는 게 정말 흥미로울 것 같아요.
text_zh: 我觉得就业市场正在重新找平衡，但是这个过程啊，走的路子跟以前很不一样，感觉这个变化可能会一直持续下去，不管市场怎么起起伏伏。这个还挺有意思的，值得继续观察。
text_es: Creo que el mercado laboral se está reequilibrando, pero se está haciendo de una manera muy distinta, los caminos están cambiando de una forma que parece que va a mantenerse a pesar de los altibajos. Va a ser muy interesante ver qué pasa.
context: Lenny asks about changes in the hiring market, and Hari explains that while the job market is shifting back toward employers having more power, some fundamental changes from the pandemic era are persisting. He believes the new pathways for job searching - like skills-based matching and values-based job seeking - represent lasting changes rather than temporary shifts.
vocabulary_highlights: holds through these ups and downs

speaker: Hari Srinivasan
text: When you were just looking at title, I think you only had one way to really prove that you had the skills. You had to have that title, which is very hard to break in. In a world where you're looking at skills, you can go through and say, 'Look, I can do these things and you could put evidence behind it.'
text_ko: 예전엔 직함(title)만 보고 판단하니까 실력을 제대로 증명할 방법이 사실상 하나밖에 없었어요. 그 직함을 가져야 했고, 그걸 얻기가 정말 어려웠죠. 그런데 이제는 실력을 보고 평가하는 쪽이라서 “제가 이런 일을 할 수 있고, 그걸 증빙할 자료도 있어요”라고 보여줄 수 있어요.
text_zh: 以前光看头衔的时候，我觉得你要证明自己有能力就只有一条路，就是必须得有那个头衔，但这个门槛特别难跨过去。现在这个看重技能的时代就不一样了，你可以直接说"你看，这些事儿我都能干"，而且还能拿出实实在在的证据来证明。
text_es: Cuando solo se fijaban en el título, creo que solo tenías una manera de demostrar realmente que tenías las habilidades. Tenías que tener ese título, y meterte ahí es súper difícil. En un mundo donde se fijan en las habilidades, puedes llegar y decir: "Mira, yo sé hacer estas cosas y te puedo dar pruebas de ello."
context: Lenny asks for tips on how product managers can improve their chances of being found by recruiters. Hari is explaining how LinkedIn's skills-first approach creates new opportunities for job seekers. Previously, candidates needed specific job titles to prove their capabilities, but now they can demonstrate relevant skills through various forms of evidence and credentials.
vocabulary_highlights: very hard to break in, put evidence behind it

speaker: Hari Srinivasan
text: I just remember driving home and calling my wife and like, 'I think I might be fired.' I'm not sure if I was fired, but he was very kind about it. He's like, 'Just come back and exit.' I think five, four weeks.
text_ko: 집으로 운전해 가던 길에 아내한테 전화해서 "나 아마 해고된 것 같아"라고 했던 게 기억나요. 진짜 해고된 건지는 확실하지 않아요. 근데 그분이 되게 친절하게 대해주셨어요. "그냥 다시 와서 퇴사 처리하면 돼요"라고 하시더라고요. 아마 네다섯 주 정도였던 것 같아요.
text_zh: 我记得开车回家的时候给我老婆打电话，我说"我觉得我可能被炒了。"我也不确定是不是真的被开了，但他人还挺好的。他说"你回来办个离职手续就行。"我想是五周，还是四周来着。
text_es: Recuerdo que iba manejando a casa y le marqué a mi esposa y le dije, 'Creo que me corrieron.' No estaba seguro si me habían despedido, pero él fue muy gentil al respecto. Me dijo algo como, 'Solo regresa y termina tu proceso de salida.' Creo que fueron cinco, cuatro semanas.
context: Lenny asks Hari about his first product review at LinkedIn after joining through an acquisition. Hari describes how he got 'destroyed' during his first presentation because he had relied too heavily on generic advice rather than understanding LinkedIn's core mission. This moment of potential failure led to a pivotal learning experience about focusing on the company's North Star.
vocabulary_highlights: got destroyed, come back and exit

speaker: Hari Srinivasan
text: I think when people ask me to describe LinkedIn, I often start with that story because I feel like it helps cut through how decisions are made and what is seen as success here.
text_ko: 사람들이 저한테 LinkedIn을 설명해 달라고 물어보면, 저는 보통 그 이야기를 먼저 꺼내요. 그게 여기서 의사결정이 어떻게 이뤄지는지와 무엇을 성공으로 보는지를 더 잘 보여주거든요.
text_zh: 我觉得当别人让我介绍LinkedIn的时候，我经常会从那个故事开始讲，因为我感觉这样能让大家更清楚地了解我们这里是怎么做决策的，什么才算是成功。
text_es: Cuando me preguntan cómo describiría LinkedIn, casi siempre empiezo con esa historia porque siento que ayuda a entender realmente cómo se toman las decisiones aquí y qué consideramos un éxito.
context: Hari continues reflecting on his difficult first product review at LinkedIn. He's explaining how this experience taught him about LinkedIn's decision-making culture and North Star of connecting people to economic opportunity. Despite LinkedIn being a complex company with multiple business lines, this clear mission helps cut through complexity when making product decisions.
vocabulary_highlights: helps cut through

speaker: Hari Srinivasan
text: I do think it's exceptional leadership, and I've learned so much from watching it and how it gets operated. I do think the culture has a pretty high immune system now in the sense that when you aren't operating by that, people can see it and they operate against it.
text_ko: 정말 탁월한 리더십이라고 생각해요. 지켜보면서 리더십이 어떻게 발휘되고 운영되는지도 많이 배웠어요. 조직 문화에는 이제 꽤 강한 면역 체계(immune system)가 있어서, 그 방식대로 운영하지 않으면 사람들이 금방 알아차리고 거기에 맞서 행동해요.
text_zh: 我觉得这真的是很了不起的领导力，我通过观察学到了很多，看他们是怎么运作的。我觉得现在这个企业文化已经有了很强的免疫力，就是说如果你不按这套来，大家一眼就能看出来，而且会自然地去纠正。
text_es: Sí creo que es un liderazgo excepcional, y he aprendido muchísimo viendo cómo funciona y cómo se maneja. Creo que la cultura ya tiene un sistema inmunológico bastante fuerte en el sentido de que cuando no estás operando así, la gente se da cuenta y actúa en contra.
context: Lenny asks how LinkedIn operationalizes its North Star of connecting people to economic opportunity. Hari explains that it comes from consistent repetition by leadership over many years. The concept of a 'high immune system' refers to how the culture now automatically rejects decisions or behaviors that don't align with the core mission.
vocabulary_highlights: pretty high immune system, operate against it

speaker: Heidi Helfand
text: Reteaming is hard. Reorgs are hard. You can't lump them all into one thing with oh, it's all great all the time. No, it's not. If we could just build the software, deliver to the customer, get the product market fit, hey, have we delighted them or not? If only it could be that easy. No, we have the people layer, so let's focus there too.
text_ko: 팀 재구성(reteaming)은 정말 힘들어요. 조직 개편(reorgs)도 마찬가지고요. 이걸 다 한꺼번에 놓고 '아, 항상 다 잘돼요'라고 말할 수는 없어요. 아니에요, 그렇지 않아요. 만약 그냥 소프트웨어만 만들고 고객에게 전달해서 제품-시장 적합(product-market fit)만 맞추면, 고객을 정말 기쁘게 했는지 여부만 보면 된다면 얼마나 좋겠어요. 그렇게만 쉬웠으면 좋겠지만, 사람 측면(people layer)이 있으니 거기도 집중해야 해요.
text_zh: 重组团队很难搞，公司重组也很难搞。你不能把这些事儿都混在一起说"哎呀，反正都挺好的"。不是这样的。要是我们只要专心写代码、交付给客户、找到产品市场契合点(product market fit)，看看用户满不满意就行了，那该多好。要真能这么简单就好了。但问题是还有人的因素在里面，所以我们也得把这块儿重视起来。
text_es: Reorganizar equipos es difícil. Las reestructuraciones son difíciles. No puedes meter todo en el mismo saco diciendo "ay, todo es genial siempre". No, no lo es. Si pudiéramos simplemente desarrollar el software, entregárselo al cliente, conseguir el encaje producto-mercado (product market fit), oye, ¿los hemos dejado contentos o no? Ojalá fuera así de sencillo. Pero no, tenemos el factor humano, así que enfoquémonos también en eso.
context: At the opening of the podcast, Heidi sets the foundation for why organizational change and team restructuring matters. She acknowledges that while the ultimate goal is building great products and achieving product-market fit, there's an additional complexity layer that many companies overlook - the human element of how teams are organized and how they change over time.
vocabulary_highlights: lump them all into one thing, people layer

speaker: Heidi Helfand
text: I think a lot of the things that I would read about teams just are naturally focused on, well, you want to build things that customers love. You want it to be an enjoyable experience, you want to deliver on time. There's a reason we're there as a business, but there's also a lot of company building that happens in building the people structures and just when you go from one to many to a multitude, there's a lot of work that goes into it.
text_ko: 제가 팀(teams)에 대해 읽는 많은 얘기들은 대체로 '고객(customers)이 좋아할 것을 만들어라', '사용자 경험이 즐거워야 한다', '제때 전달하라' 같은 데 초점이 맞춰져 있어요. 사업(business)으로서 우리가 존재하는 이유가 분명 있긴 하지만, 인력 구조(people structures)를 세우는 등 회사를 만들어 가는 과정(company building)에서도 할 일이 정말 많아요. 특히 한 사람에서 여러 명으로, 그다음 훨씬 많은 규모로 확장할 때 들어가는 일이 엄청 많죠.
text_zh: 我觉得很多关于团队管理的文章，讲的都是那些基本的东西，比如要做出客户喜欢的产品，要让用户体验好，要按时交付。这些确实是我们做生意的根本，但是呢，真正搭建公司的过程中，还有很多是关于人的架构建设。你想想，从一个人到一个小团队，再到一大帮人，这中间要做的工作可多了去了。
text_es: Creo que muchas de las cosas que leo sobre equipos se enfocan naturalmente en lo obvio: quieres crear productos que los clientes amen, quieres que sea una experiencia agradable, quieres entregar a tiempo. Hay una razón por la cual estamos ahí como negocio, pero también hay muchísimo trabajo de construcción empresarial que pasa cuando desarrollas las estructuras de personal, y cuando pasas de uno a muchos a una multitud, hay un montón de trabajo detrás de eso.
context: Lenny asks Heidi to elaborate on the 'people layer' concept she mentioned earlier. Heidi explains that while most business advice focuses on product delivery and customer satisfaction, there's an equally important but often overlooked aspect of company building - designing and managing the human structures and team organizations as companies scale from small startups to large organizations.
vocabulary_highlights: from one to many to a multitude

speaker: Heidi Helfand
text: So we rolled these whiteboards out and it had the team structure with everyone's names on it. It had the name of the team, the mission of the team, how many open slots for hiring across all of these different teams, and then people's names in their existing team positions. And people were invited to look, give feedback. They identified mistakes that we had in the design, 'Oh, this team might be better over here and here's why.' And people had the opportunity to see opportunities within their own company that they might say, 'Hey, I'm interested in this, might I be considered for this?'
text_ko: 그래서 저희는 화이트보드(whiteboards)를 공개했어요. 거기에는 팀 구조(team structure)와 각 사람 이름이 적혀 있었고, 팀 이름, 팀 미션(mission), 여러 팀에 걸쳐 몇 자리의 채용 공석(open slots)이 있는지도 표시돼 있었어요. 사람들은 자신의 현재 맡은 자리도 확인할 수 있었고, 와서 보고 피드백을 달라고 초대했어요. 그러다 보니 설계상의 실수들을 발견하더라고요 — “아, 이 팀은 여기 있는 것보다 저쪽이 더 맞을 것 같아요, 이유는요…” 하고요. 또 직원들은 회사 안에서 “저거 관심 있는데, 저 자리에 고려해주실 수 있나요?”라고 직접 말할 기회도 갖게 됐어요.
text_zh: 所以我们就把这些白板推出去了，上面有团队架构，每个人的名字都在上面。有团队名称，团队使命，各个团队还有多少招聘名额，然后现有团队成员的名字和职位。大家都可以过来看看，给反馈。他们发现了我们设计中的一些问题，比如"哦，这个团队放在那边可能更好，原因是这样的。"而且大家有机会看到公司内部的机会，可能会说"嘿，我对这个感兴趣，能不能考虑一下我？"
text_es: Entonces sacamos estas pizarras y tenían toda la estructura de equipos con los nombres de todos. Tenía el nombre del equipo, la misión del equipo, cuántas vacantes había para contratar en todos estos diferentes equipos, y después los nombres de las personas en sus puestos actuales. E invitamos a la gente a que echara un vistazo y diera su opinión. Identificaron errores que teníamos en el diseño, "Ah, este equipo tal vez funcionaría mejor acá y te explico por qué." Y la gente tuvo la oportunidad de ver oportunidades dentro de su propia empresa donde pudieran decir, "Oye, esto me interesa, ¿me considerarían para esto?"
context: Lenny asks about how to take advantage of reorg opportunities for career advancement. Heidi shares a story about transparent reorganization at Procore, where they used 'whiteboard reteaming' - a method inspired by Spotify where leadership visualized the new team structure on whiteboards and invited all 80 affected employees to provide input and express interest in different roles before finalizing the changes.
vocabulary_highlights: open slots, might I be considered for this

speaker: Heidi Helfand
text: There's another framework that I really like. I don't think it's in my book, but I've written about it in my new book, but it's called RIDE. And we had a chief people officer at Procore and she's now at UKG, Pat Wadors. She taught us the RIDE framework for decision making clarity and it's who's requesting the change, who can give input to the change, who's the decider on the change, and who's going to execute on the change?
text_ko: 제가 정말 좋아하는 다른 프레임워크가 하나 있어요. 제 책에는 아마 안 실렸던 것 같은데, 새 책에는 썼어요. RIDE 프레임워크(RIDE)라고 해요. Procore에 있을 때 Chief People Officer(최고 인사 책임자)이셨고 지금은 UKG에 계신 팻 와더스(Pat Wadors)님이 우리에게 의사결정을 더 명확하게 하는 RIDE 프레임워크를 알려주셨어요. RIDE는 누가 변경을 요청하는지, 누가 변경에 대해 의견을 줄 수 있는지, 누가 최종 결정을 내리는지, 그리고 누가 실행할지를 구분한 거예요.
text_zh: 还有一个框架我特别喜欢。我记得之前那本书里没写，但新书里有提到，叫RIDE。我们以前在Procore有个首席人事官Pat Wadors，她现在在UKG，是她教给我们这个RIDE框架(RIDE framework)，专门用来理清决策流程的。就是说，谁提出要做这个改变，谁可以提意见，谁来拍板决定，还有谁负责去执行？
text_es: Hay otro modelo que me gusta mucho. No creo que esté en mi libro, pero sí lo escribí en mi nuevo libro, y se llama RIDE. Teníamos una directora de personas en Procore y ahora está en UKG, Pat Wadors. Ella nos enseñó el modelo RIDE para tener claridad en la toma de decisiones y es: quién está pidiendo el cambio, quién puede dar su opinión sobre el cambio, quién es el que decide sobre el cambio, y quién va a ejecutar el cambio.
context: Lenny asks about how to manage the complexity of involving teams in reorganization decisions. Heidi introduces the RIDE framework (Request, Input, Decide, Execute) created by Pat Wadors, which clarifies roles and responsibilities in organizational changes. This framework helps avoid confusion about who has decision-making authority versus who can provide input during team restructuring processes.
vocabulary_highlights: decision making clarity

speaker: Heidi Helfand
text: So taking a team off to the side, giving that team process freedom. They didn't want us distracted from the drag. When you're working on an existing product line, you get this cadence and it can become a mature cadence. Maybe people work in two weeks or one week now, but when you're working on something new, you need faster iteration loops. And our founders knew that need.
text_ko: 그래서 한 팀을 따로 떼어 놓고, 그 팀에겐 프로세스 자율성(process freedom)을 줬어요. 그들은 우리가 핵심 업무에서 벗어나 방해받길 원하지 않았어요. 기존 제품 라인에서 일할 땐 일정한 리듬(cadence)이 생기고 그 리듬이 익숙해질 수 있어요. 요즘은 사람들 대부분 2주 단위나 1주 단위로 일하지만, 새로운 걸 만들 때는 더 빠른 반복 주기(iteration loop)가 필요해요. 우리 창업자들은 그 필요성을 잘 알고 있었어요.
text_zh: 所以把团队拉出来单独搞，给他们流程上的自由度。他们不想让我们被那些拖后腿的事情分心。你在做现有产品线的时候，会有个固定节奏，而且可能变得很成熟很稳定。可能大家习惯了两周或者一周一个周期，但是做新东西的时候，你需要更快的迭代循环(iteration loops)。我们创始人很清楚这个需求。
text_es: Así que apartamos a un equipo, les dimos libertad total en sus procesos. No querían que nos distrajéramos de las trabas del día a día. Cuando trabajas en una línea de productos que ya existe, agarras un ritmo y puede volverse un ritmo muy establecido. A lo mejor la gente trabaja en sprints de dos semanas o una semana, pero cuando trabajas en algo nuevo, necesitas ciclos de iteración mucho más rápidos. Y nuestros fundadores sabían perfectamente esa necesidad.
context: Heidi shares the story of how Expertcity (which became GoTo products) successfully pivoted by using an 'isolation' reteaming pattern. When their original marketplace product failed, leadership created a small isolated team to work on GoToMyPC with complete process freedom. Heidi explains that existing product teams develop established rhythms that work for mature products, but new innovations require much faster iteration cycles.
vocabulary_highlights: process freedom, distracted from the drag, mature cadence, faster iteration loops
topics: Product Management, Starting a Company, Strategy & Planning

speaker: Heidi Helfand
text: And so, one, separate location. There's another story in the book about a team that incubated a product idea within Citrix and they were in a garage of all places, so they were really isolated. But just put the team in a different region, make it that area. That's number one. Number two, tell other people not to disturb this team. That's key. And hearing it from a leader is really, really important.
text_ko: 그래서 첫째, 장소를 따로 떼어 놓으세요. 책에 시트릭스 안에서 제품 아이디어를 인큐베이팅(incubated)하던 팀 이야기가 나오는데, 믿기 힘들게도 차고에 있었어요 — 완전히 고립돼 있었죠. 팀을 아예 다른 지역에 두세요. 그게 첫 번째예요. 둘째, 다른 사람들에게 이 팀을 방해하지 말라고 알려 주세요. 이게 핵심이에요. 그리고 리더가 직접 그렇게 말해 주는 게 정말 중요해요.
text_zh: 所以说，第一点，要单独找个地方。书里还有个故事，讲的是Citrix内部有个团队孵化产品想法，他们竟然是在车库里办公，真的是完全隔离开了。就是要把团队放到不同的区域，给他们划出专门的地盘。这是第一点。第二点，要告诉其他人别去打扰这个团队。这很关键。而且这话得从领导嘴里说出来，这真的非常非常重要。
text_es: Entonces, primero, que estén en un lugar aparte. Hay otra historia en el libro sobre un equipo que desarrolló una idea de producto dentro de Citrix y estaban en un garaje, imagínate, o sea, súper aislados. Pero simplemente pon al equipo en otra zona, que sea su espacio. Eso es lo primero. Lo segundo, diles a los demás que no molesten a este equipo. Eso es clave. Y que lo diga un líder es súper, súper importante.
context: Lenny asks about how to make isolated innovation teams successful, since the 'startup within a company' approach often fails. Heidi provides concrete advice for the isolation reteaming pattern: physically separate the team, have leadership explicitly protect them from interruptions, and ensure they have process freedom to work differently from the main organization.
vocabulary_highlights: incubated a product idea, not to disturb
topics: Product Management, Starting a Company, Leadership & Management

speaker: Heidi Helfand
text: So you need to shed their skin of the other things that they're working on. If you take a bigger picture, kind of forest through the trees picture, you want people pairing and switching pairs so they're not single owners of the system. So when they have an opportunity to do something that could be really important to the company beyond one of these isolated teams, they can fade out and not be the only owner that has to transfer knowledge and then field questions for two years on how that system works.
text_ko: 그래서 그 사람들이 하고 있는 다른 업무들의 부담은 덜어줘야 해요. 좀 더 큰 그림(big picture)에서 보면, 사람들이 페어링(pairing)을 하고 페어를 바꿔가면서(switching pairs) 일해서 누구도 시스템의 유일한 담당자(single owner)이 되지 않게 해야 해요. 그래야 한 사람이 고립된 팀을 넘어 회사에 정말 중요한 일을 맡게 될 기회가 생겼을 때 역할을 줄여 빠져나와도 되고, 지식 이전(knowledge transfer)을 혼자 모두 떠맡고 앞으로 2년 동안 시스템 작동 방식에 대한 문의(field questions)에 홀로 답해야 하는 상황을 피할 수 있어요.
text_zh: 所以你得让他们放下手头的其他事情。从大局来看，就是要让大家结对工作，而且要轮换搭档，这样就不会出现某个系统只有一个人懂的情况。这样一来，当有机会去做对公司真正重要的事情，而不是局限在某个孤立的小团队里时，他们就可以顺利脱身，不用担心自己是唯一的负责人，还得花两年时间去做知识交接和回答各种系统问题。
text_es: Entonces necesitas que se despeguen de las otras cosas en las que están trabajando. Si lo ves desde una perspectiva más amplia, digamos el panorama general, lo que buscas es que la gente trabaje en parejas y vaya rotando esas parejas para que no sean los únicos dueños del sistema. Así, cuando tengan la oportunidad de hacer algo que realmente pueda ser importante para la empresa, más allá de estos equipos aislados, pueden ir saliendo gradualmente sin ser los únicos responsables que tienen que transferir el conocimiento y después estar respondiendo preguntas durante dos años sobre cómo funciona ese sistema.
context: Continuing her advice on successful isolation teams, Heidi explains how companies can prepare for this type of reteaming by building knowledge redundancy. She advocates for pair programming and regular switching of pairs so that no single person becomes the sole owner of critical systems, which makes it easier for people to join special projects without leaving knowledge gaps behind.
vocabulary_highlights: shed their skin, forest through the trees, single owners of the system, fade out, field questions

speaker: Hila Qu
text: PLG I always say is actually fundamentally DLG, data led growth. So when you give away your free product, what you want to get in exchange are two things. One is a broader reach because free product spread itself is lower barrier to entry. Two, you want to understand the usage behavior of those free users, which features do they use and which features kind of correlates with a higher conversion rate, retention rate, all of that.
text_ko: 제가 항상 말하듯 제품 주도 성장(PLG)은 사실 근본적으로 데이터 주도 성장(data-led growth, DLG)이에요. 그래서 무료 제품을 제공할 때 얻고 싶은 건 크게 두 가지예요. 하나는 더 넓은 도달 범위(reach)를 확보하는 것 — 무료 제품은 진입 장벽이 낮아서 자체적으로 더 잘 퍼지거든요. 둘째는 그 무료 사용자들의 사용 행태를 이해하는 거예요. 어떤 기능을 쓰는지, 어떤 기능 사용이 전환율(conversion rate)이나 유지율(retention rate) 상승과 연관되는지 같은 것들이요.
text_zh: 我总是说PLG其实本质上就是DLG，就是数据驱动增长(data led growth)。当你免费提供产品的时候，你想要换取两样东西。第一个是更广的覆盖面，因为免费产品传播起来门槛更低嘛。第二个，你要搞清楚那些免费用户的使用习惯，他们用哪些功能，哪些功能跟更高的转化率、留存率这些指标有关联。
text_es: Siempre digo que PLG en realidad es fundamentalmente DLG, crecimiento guiado por datos (data led growth). Entonces cuando das tu producto gratis, lo que quieres obtener a cambio son dos cosas. Una es mayor alcance porque un producto gratuito se extiende solo, tiene menos barreras de entrada. Dos, quieres entender el comportamiento de uso de esos usuarios gratuitos, qué funcionalidades usan y cuáles se correlacionan con una mayor tasa de conversión, retención, todo eso.
context: Lenny is discussing product-led growth (PLG) strategy with Hila, who is explaining the fundamental principles of PLG. Hila emphasizes that successful product-led growth is essentially data-led growth (DLG). She explains that when companies offer free products to users, they should expect two key benefits in return: broader market reach through easier adoption, and valuable behavioral data about user preferences and feature usage patterns.
vocabulary_highlights: fundamentally, broader reach, lower barrier to entry, correlates with
topics: Product Management, Growth & Marketing, Strategy & Planning

speaker: Hila Qu
text: If you don't have a foundation of data and understanding of how to analyze those data, you are giving a way of free product for nothing. Like you are really not being able to utilize all of that to build your PLG motion.
text_ko: 데이터의 기반과 그것을 어떻게 분석할지에 대한 이해가 없다면, 사실상 제품을 공짜로 제공하는 셈이에요. 그걸 제대로 활용해서 제품 주도 성장(PLG motion)을 만들어내지도 못해요.
text_zh: 如果你没有数据基础，也不懂怎么分析这些数据的话，那你就等于白白送产品，什么都得不到。就是说你根本没法利用这些东西来搭建你的PLG模式(PLG motion)。
text_es: Si no tienes una base sólida de datos y no sabes cómo analizarlos, básicamente estás regalando tu producto. O sea, no estás aprovechando toda esa información para construir tu estrategia PLG (product-led growth).
context: Hila is explaining common pitfalls companies encounter when trying to implement product-led growth. She emphasizes that offering a free product without proper data infrastructure is essentially worthless. Companies need robust data collection and analysis capabilities to understand user behavior, feature usage patterns, and conversion indicators, or they miss the core benefit of PLG strategies.
vocabulary_highlights: giving a way of free product for nothing, utilize all of that, build your PLG motion
topics: Product Management, Growth & Marketing, Strategy & Planning

speaker: Hila Qu
text: I wouldn't say it's shifted completely because I always believe you don't need to be a PLG purist. Meaning there are kind of people who are like, 'PLG is the future. It's only thing, you don't need sales.' Right? I was never like that, but recently by working with a few of my clients, I witnessed in reality many startups actually are having both.
text_ko: 완전히 바뀌었다고는 못 해요. 저는 PLG(제품 주도 성장, Product-Led Growth)만 고집할 필요는 없다고 항상 생각해요. 어떤 사람들은 “PLG가 미래고 그게 전부라서 영업은 필요 없다”고 하기도 하죠. 저는 그런 쪽은 아니었어요. 그런데 최근 몇몇 고객사와 함께 일하면서 실제로 많은 스타트업이 PLG와 영업을 둘 다 병행하고 있다는 걸 보게 됐어요.
text_zh: 我不会说完全转变了，因为我一直认为你不需要做PLG的纯粹主义者。就是有些人会说"PLG就是未来，这就是唯一的路，你根本不需要销售团队。"对吧？我从来不是那样想的，但是最近跟几个客户合作下来，我亲眼看到现实中很多初创公司其实是两手都在抓的。
text_es: No diría que ha cambiado completamente porque siempre he creído que no necesitas ser un purista del PLG (product-led growth). O sea, hay gente que dice "PLG es el futuro, es lo único que importa, no necesitas ventas." ¿No? Yo nunca fui así, pero últimamente trabajando con algunos de mis clientes, he visto que en la realidad muchas startups en realidad están manejando ambas cosas.
context: Lenny asks Hila whether her thinking about product-led growth has evolved since writing her popular series on the topic. Hila explains that she's never been an extreme advocate who believes PLG should completely replace sales teams. A 'PLG purist' refers to someone who thinks product-led growth is the only viable strategy and that traditional sales approaches are obsolete. Hila advocates for a balanced approach where companies can benefit from both PLG and sales motions.
vocabulary_highlights: PLG purist, witnessed in reality
topics: Growth & Marketing, Strategy & Planning, Leadership & Management

speaker: Hila Qu
text: I think it is easier if you have PLG from early on. If you are pure sales led, you try to add PLG, that's the harder thing to change basically.
text_ko: 초기부터 제품 주도 성장(PLG)을 기반으로 하면 더 쉬운 것 같아요. 반대로 순전히 영업 주도(sales-led) 구조에서 PLG를 도입하려고 하면 그걸 바꾸는 건 본질적으로 더 어렵거든요.
text_zh: 我觉得如果你从一开始就做产品驱动增长(PLG)会容易很多。如果你纯粹是靠销售驱动的，后面再想加PLG，基本上就很难转型了。
text_es: Creo que es más fácil si tienes PLG desde el principio. Si tu modelo es puramente de ventas tradicionales y después tratas de añadir PLG (product-led growth), eso es lo más difícil de cambiar, básicamente.
context: Lenny and Hila are discussing the trend of companies eventually needing both product-led growth and sales-led approaches. Hila explains the strategic timing considerations for implementing these different go-to-market motions. She suggests that starting with PLG from the beginning provides advantages, while traditional sales-led companies face greater challenges when trying to retrofit product-led components into their existing business model.
vocabulary_highlights: pure sales led, harder thing to change basically
topics: Strategy & Planning, Starting a Company, Growth & Marketing

speaker: Hila Qu
text: The red flags I've seen basically sometimes, first of all, they think about PLG equals launch of free version or launch of free trial. They made this assumption in their head, 'Oh, I already have a product. I already have a software that's working, customers are using. Now if I add a free version, if I open a free trial, that's it.'
text_ko: 제가 본 위험 신호 중 하나는, 사람들이 PLG(Product-Led Growth)를 무료 버전(free version) 출시나 무료 체험(free trial) 시작과 동일시한다는 점이에요. 머릿속으로는 "이미 제품도 있고 소프트웨어도 잘 돌아가고 고객들도 쓰고 있으니까, 여기서 무료 버전만 추가하거나 무료 체험을 열면 그걸로 끝이라고 생각해요"라고 가정해버리는 경우가 많아요.
text_zh: 我见过的一些危险信号基本上就是，首先，他们觉得PLG就等于推出免费版本或者免费试用。他们脑子里有个想法，"哦，我已经有产品了，已经有能用的软件了，客户也在用。现在我只要加个免费版本，开放个免费试用，这就搞定了。"
text_es: Las señales de alarma que he visto básicamente a veces, para empezar, piensan que PLG es igual a lanzar una versión gratuita o lanzar una prueba gratis. Se meten esta idea en la cabeza de 'Ah, ya tengo un producto. Ya tengo un software que funciona, los clientes lo están usando. Ahora si le agrego una versión gratuita, si abro una prueba gratis, ya está.'
context: Lenny asks Hila about warning signs that indicate a company isn't truly committed to implementing product-led growth successfully. Hila identifies a major red flag: oversimplifying PLG implementation. Many leaders mistakenly believe that simply adding a free trial or freemium version to their existing product automatically creates a successful PLG motion, when in reality it requires comprehensive strategy, dedicated resources, and long-term commitment.
vocabulary_highlights: red flags, made this assumption in their head, that's it
topics: Product Management, Strategy & Planning, Leadership & Management

speaker: Hila Qu
text: I always take a very long-term view for writing. I enjoy writing myself. Spend actually four months on that one. After it's published, I see a lot of shares kind of and people writing very long summary of it. That's always very encouraging and also many people I didn't expect reading it reach out to me, let me know, 'Hey, I read that.'
text_ko: 저는 글을 쓸 때 항상 아주 장기적으로 봐요. 글 쓰는 걸 저도 즐기고요. 사실 그 글 하나에 실제로 네 달 정도 썼어요. 발행하고 나면 공유가 많이 되고 어떤 분들은 아주 긴 요약을 올리기도 해요. 그런 반응이 늘 큰 힘이 되고, 예상치 못한 분들이 연락해서 '읽었어요'라고 알려줄 때도 있어요.
text_zh: 我写东西一直都是从长远角度考虑的。我自己很享受写作这个过程，光是那一篇就花了四个月时间。发表之后，我看到很多人转发，还有人写了很长的总结，这真的很鼓舞人心。更让我意外的是，很多我完全没想到的人都主动联系我，跟我说："嘿，我看了你那篇文章。"
text_es: Siempre tengo una visión a muy largo plazo cuando escribo. Me encanta escribir, la verdad. En ese artículo me pasé como cuatro meses trabajándolo. Después de publicarlo, veo que se comparte bastante y la gente hace resúmenes súper largos. Eso siempre me motiva un montón, y además muchas personas que no esperaba que lo fueran a leer me contactan para decirme "Oye, me leí tu artículo."
context: Lenny asks Hila about the impact of her highly popular guest posts on product-led growth that appeared in his newsletter. Hila explains her patient, methodical approach to creating content and the unexpected networking benefits that resulted. She spent four months crafting the series, which led to widespread sharing, detailed reader summaries, and connections with influential people in the industry she hadn't previously known.
vocabulary_highlights: long-term view, very encouraging, people I didn't expect

speaker: Hilary Gridley
speaker_expertise: Product Strategy, Team Building, Marketing Strategy
text: Product leadership is the type of role where if you are not in control of the voices in your head, they will eat you alive.
text_ko: 프로덕트 리더십(product leadership)은 머릿속의 목소리들을 통제하지 못하면 그게 자신을 완전히 갉아먹어 버리는 자리예요.
text_zh: 做产品负责人这个岗位就是这样，如果你搞不定脑子里那些声音，它们会把你逼疯的。
text_es: El liderazgo de producto es el tipo de puesto donde si no tienes control sobre tus pensamientos y dudas internas, te van a destrozar por completo.
context: Lenny asks Hilary about helping team members learn to take a punch and deal with hardship. Hilary explains that product leadership is particularly challenging because you're constantly making decisions without clear right answers while everyone looks to you for clarity. This advice came from her former boss when she started reporting directly to a CEO during a pivotal career moment.
vocabulary_highlights: eat you alive

speaker: Hilary Gridley
speaker_expertise: Product Strategy, Team Building, Marketing Strategy
text: I try to focus them less around how you litigate another person's impression of you and more on what is the action that you can take to counter program the narrative that you are afraid that this other person has of you. What are you going to do next to demonstrate that you are the person that you know yourself to be?
text_ko: 저는 사람들이 다른 사람이 자신을 어떻게 보는지에 대해 다투는 데 덜 신경 쓰게 하고, 대신 상대가 자신에 대해 갖고 있을 것 같아 두려운 그 서사를 바꾸기 위해 어떤 행동을 취할 수 있을지에 더 초점을 맞추게 해요(counter-program the narrative). 다음에 당신은 스스로 아는 그 사람이라는 걸 보여주기 위해 무엇을 할 건가요?
text_zh: 我试着让他们少纠结于怎么去跟别人争辩你给人的印象，而是更多地想想，你能采取什么实际行动来扭转你担心别人对你的那种看法。接下来你打算做什么来证明，你就是你自己心里清楚的那个人？
text_es: Trato de enfocarlos menos en cómo vas a pelear contra lo que otra persona piensa de ti y más en qué acciones concretas puedes tomar para cambiar esa narrativa que te da miedo que tengan de ti. ¿Qué vas a hacer ahora para demostrar que eres la persona que sabes que realmente eres?
context: Lenny discusses Hilary's specific tactics for teaching team members to deal with hardship. When team members come to her upset about something that happened at work, Hilary teaches them to focus on taking action rather than trying to argue or explain away what happened. She calls this technique 'taking a punch' - learning how to recover from setbacks or criticism.
vocabulary_highlights: litigate, counter program the narrative

speaker: Hilary Gridley
speaker_expertise: Product Strategy, Team Building, Marketing Strategy
text: I would really love it if more people were like, 'Screw it. I'm going to do something that's probably going to fail. It's important and it's worth doing and I'm going to do it well.'
text_ko: 더 많은 사람들이 '에라 모르겠다. 아마 실패할지도 모르지만 해볼 거야. 중요한 일이니까 해볼 가치가 있고, 제대로 해낼 거야.'라고 했으면 정말 좋겠어요.
text_zh: 我特别希望更多人能有这种想法："管它呢，我就要去做一件可能会失败的事。这事儿很重要，值得去做，而且我要把它做好。"
text_es: Me encantaría que más gente dijera, 'Al carajo. Voy a hacer algo que probablemente va a fallar. Es importante, vale la pena hacerlo, y lo voy a hacer bien.'
context: Lenny asks about the importance of helping people learn to take on hard challenges. Hilary explains that in today's uncertain environment with AI disruption and layoffs, people are gravitating toward safe choices they're likely to succeed at. She wishes more people would embrace difficult, important problems even if they might fail.
vocabulary_highlights: screw it

speaker: Hilary Gridley
speaker_expertise: Product Strategy, Team Building, Marketing Strategy
text: People think that the game is all about influencing the CEO, influencing the people around them. You come up thinking like you're the protagonist. But in the story of work, you are probably not the protagonist. You're not special.
text_ko: 사람들은 이 게임이 CEO(최고경영자)나 주변 사람들에게 영향력을 미치는 것이라고 생각해요. 자신이 주인공(protagonist)인 줄 알고 행동하게 돼요. 그런데 일이라는 이야기에서는 아마 당신이 주인공이 아닐 거예요. 특별하진 않아요.
text_zh: 很多人以为职场就是要搞定CEO，搞定他身边的那些人。刚进公司就觉得自己是主角。但是在职场这出戏里，你很可能不是主角。你没那么特别。
text_es: La gente piensa que todo el juego se trata de influir en el CEO, de influir en la gente que lo rodea. Llegas pensando que eres el protagonista. Pero en la historia del trabajo, probablemente no eres el protagonista. No eres especial.
context: Lenny asks about when your leader tells you to do something you disagree with. Hilary shares advice she received from a former Coinbase CPO about reporting to CEOs. Many people mistakenly think their job is to convince the CEO of their vision, but actually the job is to understand the CEO's vision and operationalize it effectively.
vocabulary_highlights: you're the protagonist

speaker: Hilary Gridley
speaker_expertise: Product Strategy, Team Building, Marketing Strategy
text: I think there's so much cool stuff we're doing right now. And if you are really in it just for pure love of the game, you just love product management, why are you building products for people exactly like you who have all your exact same at a company that sells to other companies that doesn't worry about pricing? I wish that the people who have this pure love of product management would see more of that applied to building for low income people, building for social services, things like that, that really, really need that kind of work.
text_ko: 지금 우리가 하고 있는 일들 중 정말 멋진 것들이 많다고 생각해요. 그리고 만약 진짜로 단순히 제품 관리(product management)를 순수하게 사랑해서 하는 사람이라면, 왜 자기와 똑같은 사람들—같은 배경에 있고 가격 걱정도 별로 하지 않는, 다른 회사에 파는(B2B) 고객들—을 위해서만 제품을 만드는 걸까요? 저는 제품을 진심으로 사랑하는 사람들이 그 열정을 저소득층을 위한 제품 개발이나 사회복지(social services) 같은 분야에 더 썼으면 해요. 그런 곳들이 정말로 그런 노력을 절실히 필요로 하거든요.
text_zh: 我觉得我们现在做的很多东西都挺酷的。但如果你真的是纯粹热爱这个行业，真的喜欢产品管理(product management)，那你为什么要给和你一模一样的人做产品呢？在一个卖给其他公司、完全不用担心定价的公司里，给那些跟你背景完全相同的人做产品？我特别希望那些真正热爱产品管理的人能把这份热情用到为低收入人群做产品上，为社会服务做产品，做这些真正需要这种专业能力的事情。
text_es: Creo que estamos haciendo un montón de cosas increíbles ahora mismo. Y si de verdad estás en esto por pura pasión, porque te encanta la gestión de productos (product management), ¿por qué construyes productos solo para gente exactamente igual a ti, que tiene exactamente las mismas cosas que tú, en una empresa que le vende a otras empresas y no se preocupa por los precios? Ojalá que la gente que tiene esta pasión genuina por la gestión de productos pudiera enfocarla más en construir para personas de bajos ingresos, para servicios sociales, ese tipo de cosas que realmente, realmente necesitan ese trabajo.
context: Lenny mentions Hilary's view that too many PMs are playing on easy mode. Hilary explains her 'hot take' that while she appreciates discussions about craft and taste in product management, she wishes more people with genuine love for building products would tackle harder problems like building for underserved populations rather than just building for people like themselves at well-funded companies.
vocabulary_highlights: pure love of the game

speaker: Hilary Gridley
speaker_expertise: Product Strategy, Team Building, Marketing Strategy
text: When I approach these conversations, I always try to think of them as, even if I don't agree with the feedback, if I don't agree with the decision, what is the insight that I'm missing? How am I wrong about this? In ways like, what would be true for this other person to be right?
text_ko: 이런 대화를 할 때 저는 항상, 설령 피드백(feedback)에 동의하지 않거나 결정에 동의하지 않더라도 제가 놓치고 있는 인사이트(insight)가 뭔지 생각하려고 해요. 제가 어디서 잘못 생각하고 있는 걸까? 다른 사람이 옳으려면 어떤 게 사실이어야 할까? 이런 식으로요.
text_zh: 每次遇到这种对话，我都会这样想：就算我不认同这个反馈，不赞成这个决定，但我是不是漏掉了什么关键信息？我哪里想错了？换个角度，要怎样的情况下，对方说的才是对的？
text_es: Cuando me meto en estas conversaciones, siempre trato de pensar: aunque no esté de acuerdo con el feedback, aunque no me guste la decisión, ¿qué se me está escapando? ¿En qué me estoy equivocando? O sea, ¿qué tendría que ser cierto para que esta otra persona tenga razón?
context: Lenny asks about Hilary's approach to transparency and helping team members understand how leaders think. Hilary explains her method for building mental models of how different people in the organization think. Rather than looking for reasons to disagree with decisions, she tries to understand what would need to be true for the other person to be right.
vocabulary_highlights: what would be true for this other person to be right

speaker: Howie Liu
speaker_expertise: AI/ML Products, Product Management, Company Building
text: So basically none of it was true. I mean, the surprising thing to me was how viral this tweet went when ... Frankly, I actually look back at this person's other tweets. I think they worked at CB Insights, and the irony is the whole point of that business is to have good data, good data quality around private company data. And they just literally had incorrect numbers by a strong multiple on what our revenue scale was, what our growth rate was.
text_ko: 결국 그 말들은 거의 다 사실이 아니었어요. 그러니까, 저한텐 더 놀라웠던 게 그 트윗(tweet)이 그렇게까지 퍼진 거예요... 솔직히 그 사람 다른 트윗들도 훑어봤는데, 제 생각엔 그 사람이 CB Insights에서 일했던 것 같아요. 아이러니한 건 그 회사가 비상장 기업 데이터(private company data)의 품질(data quality)을 관리하는 곳이라는 점이에요. 그런데 우리 매출 규모(revenue scale)나 성장률(growth rate)에 대한 수치가 문자 그대로 수 배는 틀리게 잘못 올라와 있었어요.
text_zh: 所以说基本上没有一个是对的。让我意外的是这条推特居然传播得这么广，我回头看了看这个人的其他推特，他好像在CB Insights工作，讽刺的是，他们公司的核心业务就是要有好的数据，特别是私人公司数据的质量要过硬。结果他们给出的数字完全是错的，不管是我们的营收规模还是增长率，差了好几倍。
text_es: Básicamente nada de eso era cierto. O sea, lo que más me sorprendió fue lo viral que se hizo ese tweet cuando... La verdad es que me puse a revisar los otros tweets de esta persona. Creo que trabajaba en CB Insights, y la ironía es que todo el enfoque de ese negocio es tener buenos datos, buena calidad de datos sobre empresas privadas. Y literalmente tenían números completamente incorrectos, por un margen enorme, sobre el tamaño de nuestros ingresos y nuestra tasa de crecimiento.
context: Lenny asks Howie about a viral tweet that claimed Airtable was dead and had raised way more money than they were worth. Howie explains how the tweet contained completely incorrect data about Airtable's revenue and growth metrics. He notes the irony that the person who posted it worked at CB Insights, a company whose business model is built around providing accurate private company data, yet they shared completely wrong numbers.
vocabulary_highlights: by a strong multiple, take-down tweet, went super viral

speaker: Howie Liu
speaker_expertise: AI/ML Products, Product Management, Company Building
text: If you were literally founding a new company from scratch with the same mission, how would you execute on that mission using a fully AI native approach? If you can't, then you should find a buyer and then if you really care about this mission, go and start the next carnation of it.
text_ko: 만약 같은 미션으로 아예 백지에서 새 회사를 세운다고 하면, 완전한 AI 네이티브 접근(fully AI native approach)으로 그 미션을 어떻게 실행하겠어요? 그걸 못 하겠다면 회사를 사줄 인수자를 찾으세요. 그리고 그 미션을 진짜로 중요하게 생각한다면, 그 미션의 다음 버전(incarnation)을 직접 다시 시작하세요.
text_zh: 如果你真的要从零开始创立一家新公司，同样的使命，你会怎么用完全AI原生(AI native)的方法来实现？如果做不到的话，那就该找买家把公司卖了，然后如果你真的在乎这个使命，就去重新开始下一个版本。
text_es: Si literalmente fueras a fundar una empresa nueva desde cero con la misma misión, ¿cómo ejecutarías esa misión usando un enfoque completamente nativo de IA? Si no puedes hacerlo, entonces deberías buscar un comprador y luego, si realmente te importa esta misión, ve y arranca la siguiente versión de la misma.
context: Howie discusses how established companies should evaluate their position in the AI era. He argues that founders need to take a clean slate approach and honestly assess whether they can better execute their mission with AI-native methods using their existing assets, or if they'd be better off starting fresh. This is part of his framework for how legacy companies should think about AI transformation.
vocabulary_highlights: clean slate approach, next carnation

speaker: Howie Liu
speaker_expertise: AI/ML Products, Product Management, Company Building
text: If you want to cancel all your meetings for like a day or for an entire week and just go play around with every AI product you think could be relevant to Airtable, go do it.
text_ko: 하루나 일주일쯤 모든 미팅을 다 취소하고 Airtable에 쓸모 있을 것 같은 AI 제품(AI product)들을 마음껏 써보고 싶다면, 그냥 그렇게 하세요.
text_zh: 如果你想把一天或者整个星期的会议都推掉，然后去试试那些可能对Airtable有用的AI产品，那就去做吧。
text_es: Si quieres cancelar todas tus reuniones por un día o incluso por toda una semana y ponerte a jugar con todos los productos de IA que creas que podrían ser relevantes para Airtable, hazlo.
context: Lenny asks about changes Howie has made in expectations for his team to help them succeed in the AI era. Howie explains his philosophy of encouraging experimentation and play with AI tools. He actively tells his team members they can block out significant time - even a full week - to explore and experiment with AI products that might be relevant to their work at Airtable.
vocabulary_highlights: go play around with

speaker: Howie Liu
speaker_expertise: AI/ML Products, Product Management, Company Building
text: It really does become more about individual attitude. There's a strong advantage to any of those three roles who can kind of cross over into the other two. As a PM, you need to start looking more like a hybrid PM prototyper, who has some good design sensibilities?
text_ko: 결국 더 중요한 건 개인의 태도예요. 세 역할 중 어느 쪽이든 다른 두 역할로 어느 정도 넘나들 수 있는 사람에게는 확실히 유리해요. 프로덕트 매니저(PM)라면 디자인 감각(design sensibilities)을 갖춘 하이브리드형 PM 프로토타이퍼(hybrid PM prototyper)에 더 가까워져야 하지 않을까요?
text_zh: 说到底还是个人态度的问题。这三个角色中，谁能跨界到其他两个领域，谁就占大便宜。作为PM，你得往混合型PM的方向发展，既能做原型(prototyper)，又要有不错的设计感觉。
text_es: Realmente se vuelve más una cuestión de actitud personal. Hay una gran ventaja para cualquiera de esos tres roles que pueda como que cruzar hacia los otros dos. Como PM, necesitas empezar a verte más como un PM híbrido que también hace prototipos, que tenga buen ojo para el diseño, ¿no?
context: Lenny asks about which functions on product teams (PM, engineering, design) have had the most success with AI productivity tools. Howie explains that success is less about the specific role and more about individual mindset and versatility. He argues that the most successful people are those who can cross over between disciplines - like PMs who can prototype and have design skills, rather than staying siloed in traditional role boundaries.
vocabulary_highlights: cross over into, hybrid PM prototyper, design sensibilities

speaker: Howie Liu
speaker_expertise: AI/ML Products, Product Management, Company Building
text: I'm proud to say I am pretty sure I'm still the number one most expensive in inference cost user of Airtable AI, not just within our own company, but I think for a long time I was globally across all our customers vault. I mean, I'm extremely intentionally wasteful.
text_ko: 자랑스럽게 말하자면, 제 생각엔 저는 아직도 Airtable AI에서 추론 비용(inference cost) 면에서 가장 비싼 사용자 1위인 것 같아요. 우리 회사 안에서뿐 아니라 오랫동안 전 세계 모든 고객을 통틀어서도 1위였던 것 같고요. 제 말은, 저는 정말 일부러 엄청 낭비를 해요.
text_zh: 我可以很自豪地说，我应该还是推理成本(inference cost)最高的Airtable AI用户，不光是在我们公司内部，我觉得很长一段时间我在全球所有客户里都是第一名。我的意思是，我就是故意这么浪费的。
text_es: Puedo decir con orgullo que estoy bastante seguro de que sigo siendo el usuario número uno con los costos de inferencia más altos de Airtable AI, no solo dentro de nuestra empresa, sino que creo que durante mucho tiempo fui el que más gastaba a nivel global entre todos nuestros clientes. O sea, soy extremadamente despilfarrador a propósito.
context: Howie discusses his philosophy of using AI tools extensively as CEO. He explains how he personally uses AI heavily, even spending hundreds of dollars on inference costs for tasks like analyzing sales call transcripts. He describes being 'intentionally wasteful' with AI compute because the strategic insights gained are worth far more than the cost, comparing it to having a highly capable chief of staff analyze all company data.
vocabulary_highlights: inference cost, intentionally wasteful

speaker: Howie Liu
speaker_expertise: AI/ML Products, Product Management, Company Building
text: We now have what I call the fast thinking group, which officially is called AI platform, but it really means we want to just ship a bunch of new capabilities on a near weekly basis. And each of them should be truly awesome value. You should drop your jaw, how awesome it is to use this new capability in Airtable.
text_ko: 지금은 제가 '패스트 싱킹 그룹(fast thinking group)'이라고 부르는 조직이 있고, 공식 명칭은 AI 플랫폼(AI platform)이에요. 하지만 본질적으로는 거의 매주 새로운 기능을 한꺼번에 출시하고 싶다는 뜻이에요. 그리고 그 기능들 하나하나는 진짜로 압도적인 가치를 줘야 해요 — 에어테이블(Airtable)에서 이 새 기능을 써보고 입이 떡 벌어질 정도여야 해요.
text_zh: 我们现在有一个团队，我叫它"快速思考小组"，官方名字是AI平台(AI platform)，但实际上就是说我们要几乎每周都推出一堆新功能。而且每个功能都得真的超级有价值，让你用了之后会惊掉下巴，觉得"哇，在Airtable里用这个新功能也太牛了吧！"
text_es: Ahora tenemos lo que yo llamo el grupo de pensamiento rápido, que oficialmente se llama plataforma de IA, pero en realidad significa que queremos lanzar un montón de nuevas funcionalidades casi cada semana. Y cada una de ellas debería ser de un valor increíble. Debería dejarte con la boca abierta lo impresionante que es usar esta nueva funcionalidad en Airtable.
context: Howie explains a recent reorganization at Airtable inspired by Daniel Kahneman's 'Thinking, Fast and Slow' concept. The fast thinking group focuses on rapidly shipping AI capabilities weekly, while a separate slow thinking group handles more deliberate, infrastructure-heavy work. This structure allows them to move at the breakneck pace of AI-native companies while still supporting larger enterprise deployments.
vocabulary_highlights: drop your jaw, breakneck pace, near weekly basis

speaker: Howie Liu
speaker_expertise: AI/ML Products, Product Management, Company Building
text: I think you actually have to take a clean slate approach to saying, 'How would our mission best be expressed? If you were literally founding a new company from scratch with the same mission, how would you execute on that mission using a fully AI native approach?' And then, by the way, do you have useful building blocks that you can leverage from your existing product and your existing business, or are you literally worse off having this legacy asset versus starting something from scratch?
text_ko: 저는 사실 '미션(mission)을 가장 잘 표현하려면 어떻게 해야 할까? 만약 같은 미션으로 정말로 처음부터 새 회사를 세운다고 하면, 완전한 AI 네이티브(AI native) 방식으로 그 미션을 어떻게 실행하겠나?'처럼 백지 상태 접근법(clean slate approach)을 취해야 한다고 생각해요. 그리고 덧붙여, 기존 제품과 사업에서 활용할 만한 유용한 구성 요소(building blocks)가 있나요, 아니면 그 레거시 자산(legacy asset) 때문에 차라리 처음부터 새로 시작하는 게 더 나은 상황인가요?
text_zh: 我觉得你得彻底重新思考一下，问问自己'咱们的使命到底应该怎么体现？'如果你真的要从零开始创办一家新公司，使命还是一样的，你会怎么用完全AI原生(AI native)的方式来实现这个使命？然后呢，你再看看现有的产品和业务有没有什么有用的模块可以拿来用，还是说这些老资产(legacy asset)反而成了包袱，还不如从头开始？
text_es: Creo que realmente tienes que empezar desde cero y preguntarte: '¿Cómo podríamos expresar mejor nuestra misión? Si literalmente estuvieras fundando una empresa nueva desde el principio con la misma misión, ¿cómo ejecutarías esa misión usando un enfoque completamente nativo de IA?' Y luego, por cierto, ¿tienes componentes útiles que puedas aprovechar de tu producto actual y tu negocio existente, o realmente estás peor teniendo estos activos heredados (legacy assets) en lugar de empezar algo completamente de cero?
context: Howie discusses how established companies should approach AI transformation. He argues that companies can't just add AI features superficially but must fundamentally rethink their approach. This involves asking whether you can better execute your mission with your existing assets in an AI-native way, or if the legacy product actually hinders you compared to starting fresh. If the latter, he suggests selling and starting anew.
vocabulary_highlights: clean slate approach, legacy asset, AI native approach

speaker: Ian McAllister
text: The closest thing to a checklist, the post I mentioned, the Operator's Manual, that was the closest thing to, if you do these things, these specific actions, I think it'll go a long way. Because a lot of them are guided around not doing the easy pitfalls and communication mistakes like rambling. If you're asked a question and you explain and then maybe you get to the answer, if you just think, answer and then explain or sometimes answer and then shut up, that actually is a tactical thing you can do to get better at communicating.
text_ko: 체크리스트에 가장 가까운 게 제가 말한 글, 즉 운영자 매뉴얼(Operator's Manual)이었어요. 그게 만약 이런 구체적인 행동들을 따르면 꽤 도움이 될 거라고 생각해요. 많은 내용이 말이 산으로 가는 것 같거나 횡설수설하는 등 쉬운 함정과 커뮤니케이션 실수를 피하도록 짜여 있어요. 예를 들어 질문을 받으면 설명을 늘어놓다가 겨우 답에 도달하는 경우가 많은데, '먼저 답하고 그다음에 설명하기' 혹은 때로는 '답하고 그냥 그만 말하기'라고 생각하는 것만으로도 커뮤니케이션을 더 잘할 수 있는 전술이에요.
text_zh: 最接近清单的东西，就是我刚才提到的那篇文章，《操作手册》，这是最接近那种"你照着做这些具体的事情，我觉得就能有很大帮助"的东西。因为里面很多内容都是教你怎么避开那些容易犯的沟通错误，比如说话啰嗦。如果别人问你问题，你先解释一大堆，然后才给答案，其实你可以换个思路，先回答问题再解释，或者有时候回答完就闭嘴，这些都是让你沟通更有效的实用技巧。
text_es: Lo que más se parece a una lista de verificación, ese post que mencioné, el Manual del Operador, eso era lo más parecido a decir: si haces estas cosas, estas acciones específicas, creo que te va a servir un montón. Porque muchas de ellas están enfocadas en evitar las metidas de pata típicas y los errores de comunicación como irse por las ramas. Si te hacen una pregunta y tú explicas y explicas y tal vez al final llegas a la respuesta, si mejor piensas: responde primero y después explica, o a veces responde y ya, punto, eso es algo táctico que puedes hacer para comunicarte mejor.
context: Lenny asks Ian if he has any tactical advice for new PMs to improve at the core skills of communication, prioritization, and execution. Ian references his 'Operator's Manual' post, which is a collection of specific communication best practices he learned from working with senior Amazon executives. He explains that many communication failures come from simple mistakes like rambling or not directly answering questions.
vocabulary_highlights: easy pitfalls, rambling, answer and then shut up

speaker: Ian McAllister
text: Given the same amount of skill intelligence and resources, a product manager with a great innate ability to prioritize is going to generate 5X the impact of someone without that skill. My early, if you could call it success at Amazon, I think was completely dependent. It wasn't because I worked smarter or I was smarter, I worked longer hours or I was more technical than other people. I think it was just because I was one, super hungry for impact.
text_ko: 같은 기술, 지능, 자원을 가지고 있다면, 우선순위를 잘 정하는 능력이 있는 제품 관리자(product manager)가 그 능력이 없는 사람보다 5배 더 큰 영향을 미칠 거예요. 제가 아마존에서 초기에 성공했다고 할 수 있는 이유는 전적으로 그 덕분이었어요. 제가 더 똑똑해서나 더 스마트하게 일해서가 아니라, 단순히 영향력을 얻고 싶어서 정말 간절했기 때문이에요.
text_zh: 同样的技能、智商和资源条件下，一个天生就很会排优先级的产品经理，能产生的影响力是那些不具备这项技能的人的5倍。我在亚马逊早期的成功，可以说完全靠的就是这个。不是因为我比别人更聪明、工作方法更巧妙，也不是因为我加班更多或者技术更牛，我觉得就是因为我特别渴望做出影响力。
text_es: Teniendo las mismas habilidades, inteligencia y recursos, un product manager que tenga esa capacidad innata para priorizar va a generar 5 veces más impacto que alguien que no la tenga. Mi éxito inicial en Amazon, si es que se puede llamar éxito, creo que dependió completamente de eso. No fue porque trabajara más inteligentemente o fuera más inteligente, ni porque trabajara más horas o fuera más técnico que otros. Creo que fue simplemente porque tenía una hambre brutal de generar impacto.
context: Lenny asks Ian to elaborate on the three core skills new PMs should focus on: communication, prioritization, and execution. Ian explains why prioritization is such a critical skill for product managers, sharing how his own early success at Amazon wasn't due to being smarter or more technical than others, but rather his ability to prioritize effectively and his hunger for creating business impact.
vocabulary_highlights: innate ability, generate 5X the impact, super hungry for impact
topics: Product Management, Career Development, Strategy & Planning

speaker: Ian McAllister
text: Trust is just built by repeatedly setting and meeting expectations. And I think that's a good mantra to think about as a FM. Am I meeting the expectations that I set? And not just doing good things, but calling your shots, forecasting, setting a goal, and then hitting it. And if you do that repeatedly, you're going to be in pretty good shape.
text_ko: 신뢰는 기대를 반복해서 세우고 지키는 과정에서 쌓여요. 시설 관리자(Facility Manager)로서 생각해볼 만한 좋은 모토인 것 같아요. 내가 스스로 정한 기대를 잘 충족시키고 있나요? 단순히 잘하는 것만이 아니라, 내가 하겠다고 분명히 말하고, 예측하고 목표를 세워 그걸 달성하는 거예요. 이걸 반복하면 훨씬 좋은 상태가 될 거예요.
text_zh: 信任就是通过不断地设定目标然后达成目标来建立的。我觉得这对财务经理(FM)来说是个很好的座右铭。我有没有达到自己设定的预期？不光是把事情做好，而是要说到做到，做预测，定目标，然后实现它。如果你能反复做到这一点，那你的处境就会相当不错。
text_es: La confianza se construye simplemente cumpliendo una y otra vez con lo que prometemos. Y creo que esa es una buena filosofía para tener en mente como gerente financiero. ¿Estoy cumpliendo con las expectativas que yo mismo establecí? Y no se trata solo de hacer las cosas bien, sino de ser claro con tus predicciones, hacer pronósticos, fijar una meta y luego lograrla. Si haces eso de forma constante, vas a estar en muy buena posición.
context: Lenny asks about the key skills senior PMs should focus on to advance their careers. Ian discusses 'earning trust' as one of the most important skills, explaining that trust is the currency of product leadership. He defines trust-building as a process of consistently setting clear expectations and then delivering on them, rather than just doing good work without clear commitments.
vocabulary_highlights: calling your shots, in pretty good shape

speaker: Ian McAllister
text: If you forget about everything else, forget about politics, forget about promotion, or having a bigger org or whatever, if you simply wake up every day trying to have the biggest impact you can, or if you're a leader trying to use your team to have the biggest impact you can in the company, how you do every part of your day, that's a really good guiding light.
text_ko: 다른 건 다 제쳐두고, 사내 정치(politics)나 승진, 조직(org)을 더 키우는 것 같은 건 잊어버리고, 매일 자신이 낼 수 있는 가장 큰 영향(impact)을 주기 위해 일어나 노력한다면—혹은 리더로서 팀을 통해 회사에 가장 큰 영향(impact)을 주려고 한다면—하루의 모든 일을 대하는 방식이 정말 좋은 길잡이가 돼요.
text_zh: 如果你把其他那些乱七八糟的都放一边，什么办公室政治啊、升职啊、扩大团队规模啊这些，你就想着每天起来怎么能创造最大的价值，或者说你是领导的话，怎么带着团队在公司里发挥最大的作用，用这个想法来指导你一天的工作，这就是个特别好的方向标。
text_es: Si te olvidas de todo lo demás, te olvidas de la política de oficina, de los ascensos, de tener un equipo más grande o lo que sea, si simplemente cada día te levantas tratando de generar el mayor impacto posible, o si eres líder y tratas de usar tu equipo para lograr el mayor impacto en la empresa, cómo manejas cada parte de tu día, esa es una excelente brújula para guiarte.
context: Ian is sharing his philosophy on what should drive product managers and leaders in their daily work. This quote appears to be from his discussion about being 'driven by impact, not promotion' - one of the key attributes he believes separates top-tier product managers from others. He emphasizes that focusing on impact rather than career advancement paradoxically leads to better career outcomes.
vocabulary_highlights: bigger org, guiding light
topics: Career Development, Leadership & Management, Strategy & Planning

speaker: Ian McAllister
text: Most people operate within a box. There's a box of there's product management and these are the things that product managers do. And you basically build a roadmap and you prioritize features and you work with eng. And so that might be the typical kind of product scope and tech. Most of my roles were ones where I was kind of a GM but a really product focused GM and so I naturally found myself taking a much wider view of what product is across disciplines.
text_ko: 대부분 사람들은 한정된 틀 안에서 일해요. ‘프로덕트 매니지먼트(product management)가 이렇고, 프로덕트 매니저(product manager)들이 이런 일을 한다’는 식의 상자가 있죠. 보통 로드맵(roadmap)을 만들고, 기능 우선순위(prioritize features)를 정하고, 엔지니어링(eng) 팀과 협업해요. 그래서 일반적으로는 그런 프로덕트 스코프(product scope)나 기술 중심의 범위가 전형적이에요. 제가 맡았던 역할 대부분은 일종의 GM(General Manager)이었는데, 제품에 훨씬 더 집중한 GM이라서 자연스럽게 여러 분야를 아우르는 관점으로 제품을 보게 됐어요.
text_zh: 大部分人都是在一个框框里工作的。比如说产品管理就有个框框，产品经理就是做这些事儿的。你就是做个路线图(roadmap)，排排功能优先级，跟工程师们合作。这可能就是典型的产品和技术范围吧。但我做的大部分角色其实更像是GM，不过是非常专注产品的GM，所以我自然而然地就把产品看得更宽泛，会跨各个部门去思考。
text_es: La mayoría de la gente trabaja dentro de una caja. Hay una caja que dice "esto es gestión de producto y estas son las cosas que hacen los product managers". Básicamente armas un roadmap, priorizas funcionalidades y trabajas con el equipo de ingeniería. Esa podría ser la típica área de producto y tech. En la mayoría de mis roles yo era como un GM pero un GM súper enfocado en producto, entonces naturalmente me encontré tomando una perspectiva mucho más amplia de lo que es producto a través de diferentes disciplinas.
context: Lenny asks Ian to elaborate on how senior PMs can get better at 'thinking big' - one of the three key skills he recommends for more experienced product managers. Ian explains that most PMs limit themselves to traditional product management tasks, but thinking bigger means expanding your view of ownership beyond just engineering and features to include any function that affects product success, even if those functions don't report to you.
vocabulary_highlights: operate within a box, across disciplines
topics: Product Management, Leadership & Management, Strategy & Planning

speaker: Ian McAllister
text: When teams that do it wrong is they don't do that. They don't work backwards. They have something they want to build. These things look similar. These two technologies or whatever. We could combine them and then do this. And if you say we could and it's not grounded in a customer or customer's problem, you're not working backwards. And then you may use 'the working backwards process', but you already have the solution.
text_ko: 팀들이 잘하는 게 아니라 실수하는 건 바로 그걸 하지 않는다는 거예요. 워킹 백워즈(working backwards) 방식으로 일하지 않아요. 뭘 만들고 싶다는 것부터 시작하죠. 이게 비슷해 보이고, 이 두 기술을 합치면 이렇게 해볼 수 있겠다고 해요. 그런데 그 “해볼 수 있다”는 얘기가 고객이나 고객의 문제에 근거하지 않으면, 워킹 백워즈로 일하는 게 아니에요. 그래서 ‘워킹 백워즈 프로세스(working backwards process)’라는 말을 쓸 수는 있지만, 이미 해결책을 정해놓은 상태인 거예요.
text_zh: 做错的团队就是不这么干。他们不会反向推导(work backwards)。他们是先有了想做的东西，觉得这些东西看起来挺像的，这两个技术什么的，咱们可以把它们结合起来，然后这样搞。如果你说"咱们可以这样"，但这个想法不是基于客户或者客户的问题，那你就不是在反向推导。然后你可能会用"反向推导流程(working backwards process)"，但其实你已经有解决方案了。
text_es: Cuando los equipos lo hacen mal es porque no hacen eso. No trabajan hacia atrás (working backwards). Tienen algo que quieren construir. Estas cosas se ven parecidas. Estas dos tecnologías o lo que sea. Las podemos combinar y después hacer esto. Y si dices "podríamos" y no está basado en un cliente o en el problema de un cliente, no estás trabajando hacia atrás (working backwards). Y entonces puedes usar 'el proceso de trabajar hacia atrás (working backwards process)', pero ya tienes la solución.
context: Lenny asks Ian about the most common mistakes teams make when trying to implement Amazon's working backwards process. Ian explains that the biggest error is starting with a solution or technology rather than a customer problem. He describes how teams often identify existing capabilities or technologies they could combine, then retrofit a customer problem afterward, which is the opposite of true working backwards methodology.
vocabulary_highlights: grounded in, retrofit

speaker: Inbal Shani
speaker_expertise: Product Strategy, AI/ML Products, Software Development
text: The user of the AI tools to develop software needs to form a different thinking. You need to start figuring out how are you using these AI tools to help you be successful. And it's no longer just the actual code writing, it's really evolving your thinking to the big picture, to the connected experience, to connected systems, which today we just find it more in the world of more senior developers and less and less in the junior developers.
text_ko: AI 도구(AI tools)를 써서 소프트웨어를 개발하는 사람은 사고 방식 자체를 달리 가져가야 해요. 이 도구들을 어떻게 활용해서 성공을 만들지부터 고민하기 시작해야 해요. 이제는 단순히 코드 작성(code writing)만이 아니라 더 큰 그림으로 사고를 확장해 연결된 경험(connected experience)과 연결된 시스템(connected systems)을 생각해야 해요. 그런 관점은 요즘 시니어 개발자들(senior developers) 쪽에서 더 많이 보이고, 주니어 개발자들(junior developers)에겐 점점 덜 보이고 있어요.
text_zh: 用AI工具来开发软件的人得转变一下思路。你得琢磨怎么用这些AI工具帮你做成事儿。现在不光是写代码那么简单了，你得把思维格局打开，要考虑大局，考虑用户体验的连贯性，考虑系统之间怎么打通。这种思维方式现在主要还是资深开发者有，初级开发者越来越缺这块儿。
text_es: Quien usa herramientas de IA para desarrollar software necesita cambiar su forma de pensar. Tienes que empezar a entender cómo vas a usar estas herramientas de IA para tener éxito. Y ya no se trata solo de escribir código, sino de evolucionar tu mentalidad hacia el panorama general (big picture), hacia la experiencia conectada, hacia sistemas conectados - algo que hoy en día vemos más en desarrolladores senior y cada vez menos en los junior.
context: Lenny asks about how software development will be different in the future with AI tools like Copilot. Inbal explains that developers will need to shift their mindset when working with AI-powered development tools. Instead of focusing primarily on writing code, they'll need to think more systematically about architecture, user experience, and how different systems connect together - skills that are currently more common among senior developers.
vocabulary_highlights: form a different thinking, big picture, connected experience, connected systems

speaker: Inbal Shani
speaker_expertise: Product Strategy, AI/ML Products, Software Development
text: When we're looking into what's happening right now with AI, it really became table stakes on expectations among developers, and it's really central and critical for them to be able to do their job. We know that something like 92% of developers are already using AI tools.
text_ko: 지금 AI 현황을 보면, 개발자들(developers) 사이에선 이제 '기본 요건(table stakes)'이 되었고, 그게 일을 하는 데 있어 정말 핵심이자 필수 조건이에요. 이미 약 92%의 개발자들이 AI 도구(AI tools)를 사용하고 있어요.
text_zh: 我们现在看AI这块儿，对开发者来说基本上已经是必备条件了，这对他们干活儿来说真的是核心需求。我们知道大概92%的开发者已经在用AI工具了。
text_es: Cuando vemos lo que está pasando ahora mismo con la IA, realmente se volvió algo básico e indispensable en las expectativas de los desarrolladores, y es realmente central y crítico para que puedan hacer su trabajo. Sabemos que algo como el 92% de los desarrolladores ya están usando herramientas de IA.
context: Lenny asks what's overhyped versus underhyped in AI and software development. Inbal explains that AI has become a fundamental expectation in developer tooling rather than a nice-to-have feature. She shares statistics showing the widespread adoption of AI tools among developers, emphasizing how quickly these tools have become essential to the development process.
vocabulary_highlights: table stakes, central and critical

speaker: Inbal Shani
speaker_expertise: Product Strategy, AI/ML Products, Software Development
text: Most developers span less than 25, some say less than 20% of their time writing in code. So if we're able to give them half an hour back, one, they can write more code. Second, they can have a break and take a breath so we don't burn them out and they're more happy. Third, we give them more time for collaboration and creative thinking, so that sparks innovation.
text_ko: 대부분의 개발자들(developers)은 코드(code)를 작성하는 데에 25%도 채 쓰지 못하고, 어떤 분들은 20%도 안 쓴다고들 해요. 그래서 우리가 30분만 돌려줄 수 있다면, 첫째로 더 많은 코드를 작성할 수 있어요. 둘째로 한숨 돌릴 시간이 생겨 번아웃(burnout)을 막고 더 행복해져요. 셋째로 협업(collaboration)과 창의적 사고(creative thinking)에 더 많은 시간을 쓸 수 있어서 결국 혁신(innovation)을 촉발해요.
text_zh: 大部分开发者写代码的时间其实不到25%，有人说甚至不到20%。所以如果我们能给他们省出半小时，第一，他们可以写更多代码。第二，他们能歇口气，不会那么累，心情也更好。第三，给他们更多时间去协作和创新思考，这样就能激发更多创意。
text_es: La mayoría de los desarrolladores dedican menos del 25% de su tiempo, algunos dicen que menos del 20%, escribiendo código. Entonces, si logramos devolverles media hora, primero, pueden escribir más código. Segundo, pueden tomarse un respiro para no quemarse y estar más contentos. Y tercero, les damos más tiempo para colaborar y pensar de forma creativa, lo que genera innovación.
context: Lenny suggests that companies might think they need fewer engineers if AI makes them 25% more efficient. Inbal pushes back on this idea, explaining that developers already spend very little time actually writing code due to all their other responsibilities like meetings, collaboration, and legacy system maintenance. She argues that AI efficiency gains should be used to improve developer happiness and enable more innovation rather than reduce headcount.
vocabulary_highlights: burn them out, sparks innovation

speaker: Inbal Shani
speaker_expertise: Product Strategy, AI/ML Products, Software Development
text: We are in a world that there are no right metrics. There is no one metric to rule them all. It's a combination of the things that you're looking to measure out of adopting AI. The most easiest one is time, but time is, it's funny what I'm going to say, but time is not quantifiable as a success metrics because you can write really bad code really fast.
text_ko: 우리는 정답인 메트릭(metrics)이 존재하지 않는 세상에 있어요. 모든 것을 해결해주는 단 하나의 메트릭은 없고요. AI(인공지능)를 도입해서 무엇을 측정하려는지에 따라 여러 항목을 조합해야 해요. 가장 쉬운 건 시간인데, 웃긴 얘기지만 시간만으로 성공 지표(success metrics)를 삼을 수는 없어요. 왜냐하면 정말 형편없는 코드(code)를 아주 빠르게 쓸 수도 있으니까요.
