text_zh: 我们现在面临的情况是，没有什么标准的衡量指标。不存在一个万能的指标能解决所有问题。你得把各种你想要衡量的AI应用效果综合起来看。最容易衡量的就是时间，但是说出来可能有点搞笑，时间其实不能算是一个可靠的成功指标，因为你完全可以很快地写出一堆烂代码。
text_es: Estamos en un mundo donde no existen las métricas perfectas. No hay una sola métrica que lo resuelva todo. Es una combinación de las cosas que buscas medir al adoptar IA. La más fácil es el tiempo, pero el tiempo es... va a sonar raro lo que voy a decir, pero el tiempo no se puede cuantificar como métrica de éxito porque puedes escribir código pésimo muy rápido.
context: Lenny asks about success metrics for Copilot and how GitHub measures productivity gains from AI tools. Inbal explains the complexity of measuring AI effectiveness in software development. She emphasizes that simple metrics like time saved or lines of code written don't capture the full value, since developers could potentially write poor quality code faster. The challenge is finding metrics that reflect true productivity and code quality improvements.
vocabulary_highlights: one metric to rule them all, not quantifiable

speaker: Inbal Shani
speaker_expertise: Product Strategy, AI/ML Products, Software Development
text: If you try to structure innovation, you're losing that organic spark that is humanity. Imagine that someone say you have 15 minutes a day to be creative. I don't think it's the pull. So it's encouraging that thinking more than structured.
text_ko: 혁신(innovation)을 틀에 맞춰 구조화하려고 하면 인간 고유의 자연스러운 불꽃을 잃게 돼요. 누군가가 '하루에 15분만 창의적으로 해라'고 말한다고 상상해보세요 — 그게 사람들을 끌어들이는 힘이 되진 않을 거예요. 그래서 구조화된 접근보다 생각(사고)을 더 중요하게 여기는 태도가 오히려 고무적이에요.
text_zh: 如果你想把创新搞得很结构化，那你就失去了人性中那种自然的灵感火花。你想想，要是有人跟你说每天只能有15分钟时间搞创意，这根本没什么吸引力啊。所以说，应该更多地鼓励这种思维方式，而不是把它框得死死的。
text_es: Si tratas de estructurar la innovación, pierdes esa chispa natural que es lo humano. Imagínate que alguien te diga que tienes 15 minutos al día para ser creativo. No creo que esa sea la clave. Entonces se trata más de fomentar ese pensamiento que de estructurarlo.
context: Lenny asks how GitHub structures teams to allow for innovation and experimentation, similar to how Copilot emerged from their research efforts. Inbal explains that innovation at GitHub comes from everywhere - field teams, product teams, engineering, and design. She argues against overly structured approaches to innovation, believing that forcing creativity into specific time slots or rigid frameworks kills the natural human spark that drives breakthrough ideas.
vocabulary_highlights: organic spark, I don't think it's the pull

speaker: Inbal Shani
speaker_expertise: Product Strategy, AI/ML Products, Software Development
text: And I've seen that when I started doing that without building that understanding of why we need to do a change or why this is a problem that we need to go and fix it, then you don't take people with you through that journey. So really analyzing that not everyone appreciate change the way you are, not everyone has that mindset of the go, go, go, let's go do it.
text_ko: 제가 해보니 왜 변화를 해야 하는지, 왜 이 문제를 해결해야 하는지에 대한 이해를 먼저 만들지 않고 바로 시작하면 사람들을 그 여정에 함께 끌고 갈 수 없더라고요. 그래서 정말 잘 분석해봐야 해요. 모든 사람이 당신처럼 변화를 좋아하거나 '빨리빨리, 바로 해보자'라는 마인드셋(mindset)을 가진 건 아니거든요.
text_zh: 我发现如果一开始就直接动手，没有先让大家明白为什么要做这个改变，或者为什么这个问题必须得解决，那你就没法带着团队一起走。所以真的要想清楚，不是每个人都像你一样喜欢变化，不是每个人都有那种"冲冲冲，干就完了"的心态。
text_es: Y he visto que cuando empecé a hacer eso sin construir primero esa comprensión de por qué necesitamos hacer un cambio o por qué esto es un problema que tenemos que resolver, entonces la gente no te sigue en ese proceso. Así que realmente hay que analizar que no todo el mundo aprecia el cambio como tú, no todo el mundo tiene esa mentalidad de "vamos, vamos, vamos, hagámoslo".
context: Lenny asks about Inbal's biggest career failure in a new segment called 'Failure Corner.' Inbal shares her early leadership experience at TomTom where she tried to drive too much change too quickly. She learned that her high-energy, action-oriented approach didn't work when she failed to explain the reasoning behind changes or get team buy-in first. This taught her the importance of change management and taking people along on the transformation journey.
vocabulary_highlights: take people with you through that journey, go, go, go

speaker: Eeke De Miliano
speaker_expertise: Product Management, Product Strategy, B2B SaaS
text: "To what do you attribute your success?" And you can't say "luck". Because I think humble people will always say "luck" in some way, and I always kind of want to know, how self-aware are you, basically, and how curious are you? I think people have really sort of gone back and reflected on why are they where they are today really says a lot about how they think about the world.
text_ko: 성공을 어디에 돌리시겠어요? 그냥 '운'이라고만 할 순 없어요. 겸손한 사람들은 어떻게든 '운'이라고 하긴 하는데, 저는 그 사람이 얼마나 자기 인식(self-awareness)이 있고, 얼마나 호기심(curiosity)이 있는지가 궁금해요. 자신이 왜 지금 이 자리에 있게 됐는지 다시 돌아보고 성찰해보는 태도 자체가 그 사람이 세상을 어떻게 보는지를 많은 걸 말해준다고 생각해요.
text_zh: "你觉得自己的成功主要靠什么？"而且你不能说是"运气"。因为我觉得谦虚的人总会说是运气什么的，但我其实想知道的是，你到底有多了解自己，有多好奇？我觉得那些真正回过头来思考"我为什么能走到今天这一步"的人，从他们的回答就能看出他们是怎么看这个世界的。
text_es: "¿A qué atribuyes tu éxito?" Y no puedes decir "suerte". Porque creo que la gente humilde siempre va a decir "suerte" de alguna manera, y yo siempre quiero saber, básicamente, ¿qué tan consciente eres de ti mismo y qué tan curioso eres? Creo que las personas que realmente se han puesto a reflexionar y analizar por qué están donde están hoy, eso dice mucho sobre cómo ven el mundo.
context: Lenny is featuring favorite interview questions from previous podcast guests. Eeke De Miliano, former head of product at Retool and PM at Stripe, shares her go-to interview question for candidates. She explains that this question is designed to test self-awareness and curiosity, as it forces candidates to think deeply about their career journey rather than giving modest responses about luck.
vocabulary_highlights: attribute your success, gone back and reflected

speaker: Geoff Charles
speaker_expertise: B2B SaaS, Product Design, Leadership Development
text: I ask, "What's the hardest thing you've ever done?" I ask that because working at Ramp is hard, and I want to understand what hard means for them. I want to understand why it was hard. I want to understand how they overcame that difficulty, how they worked with other people to overcome that difficulty, and how much agency they had in overcoming that.
text_ko: 저는 "지금까지 해본 일 중 가장 어려웠던 게 뭐예요?"라고 물어봐요. Ramp에서 일하는 건 쉽지 않아서 그런 질문을 하는 거고, '힘들다'가 그분들한테는 구체적으로 어떤 의미인지 알고 싶어요. 왜 그게 힘들었는지, 그 어려움을 어떻게 극복했는지, 다른 사람들과는 어떻게 협력해서 해냈는지, 그리고 그 과정을 극복하는 데 본인의 주도성(agency)이 어느 정도였는지도 알고 싶어요.
text_zh: 我会问："你做过最难的事情是什么？"我之所以这么问，是因为在Ramp工作很辛苦，我想了解对他们来说"难"意味着什么。我想知道为什么那件事很难，想了解他们是怎么克服困难的，怎么和别人配合一起解决问题的，还有他们在解决问题的过程中发挥了多大的主观能动性。
text_es: Les pregunto: "¿Qué ha sido lo más difícil que has hecho en tu vida?" Hago esta pregunta porque trabajar en Ramp es exigente, y quiero entender qué significa "difícil" para ellos. Quiero saber por qué fue tan complicado, cómo lograron superarlo, cómo trabajaron con otros para salir adelante, y qué tanto control tuvieron sobre la situación para resolverlo.
context: Geoff Charles, Head of Product at Ramp, explains his favorite interview question when Lenny asks about effective ways to evaluate candidates. This question helps him assess a candidate's resilience and problem-solving abilities, which are crucial for success at Ramp since the work environment is particularly challenging and demanding.
vocabulary_highlights: how much agency they had

speaker: Shishir Mehrotra
speaker_expertise: Engineering Leadership, Growth Strategy, Team Building
text: Interestingly, all of a sudden the sharp product managers, engineers, basically every role, they very quickly find what are the one or two Eigenquestions on this topic. There's no right answer, but I'll tell you one of my favorite ones, because the product manager said, "Okay, if I had to ask two questions, the two questions I would ask, one, is it safe enough for humans or not?"
text_ko: 재밌게도, 갑자기 유능한 제품 매니저들, 엔지니어들, 사실상 모든 역할의 사람들이 이 주제에 대해 한두 가지 핵심 질문(Eigenquestions)을 아주 빠르게 찾아내요. 정답은 없지만, 제가 좋아하는 질문 중 하나를 말해볼게요. 한 제품 매니저가 "만약 제가 두 가지 질문만 해야 한다면, 제가 물어볼 두 가지 중 첫 번째는 이게 사람들에게 충분히 안전한가요, 아닌가요?"라고 했거든요.
text_zh: 有意思的是，突然间那些敏锐的产品经理、工程师，基本上各个岗位的人，都能很快找到这个话题的一两个核心问题(Eigenquestions)。虽然没有标准答案，但我跟你说一个我最喜欢的，因为那个产品经理说："好吧，如果我只能问两个问题的话，我会问的两个问题，第一个就是，这对人类来说够不够安全？"
text_es: Es interesante, de repente los product managers más avispados, los ingenieros, básicamente todos los roles, muy rápido encuentran cuáles son las una o dos preguntas fundamentales sobre este tema. No hay una respuesta correcta, pero te voy a contar una de mis favoritas, porque el product manager dijo: "Oye, si tuviera que hacer dos preguntas, las dos preguntas que haría serían: una, ¿es lo suficientemente seguro para los humanos o no?"
context: Shishir Mehrotra, CEO of Coda, describes his teleportation device interview question where candidates must identify the most important questions to ask. An "Eigenquestion" in his framework refers to the fundamental questions that unlock the most critical information needed to make strategic decisions. He explains how strong candidates quickly identify these core questions that drive all other business decisions.
vocabulary_highlights: all of a sudden, sharp product managers, Eigenquestions

speaker: Yuhki Yamashita
speaker_expertise: Product Strategy, Product Management, User Experience
text: The thought experiment for me is always, coming out of that, do I feel compelled to work on that problem? Right? No matter how boring it sounds on the surface, I think a really great product manager kind of casts something. It's like, "Well, this is why it's so existential and this is why it's so interesting, and really rallied the troops up.
text_ko: 저한테는 항상 하나의 사고 실험(thought experiment)이 있어요. 그걸 거치고 나서 이 문제에 꼭 뛰어들어 일하고 싶다는 마음이 드는지가 중요한 거예요. 표면적으로 아무리 지루해 보여도, 정말 훌륭한 프로덕트 매니저(product manager)는 뭔가를 던져요. "이게 왜 그렇게 근본적이고 흥미로운지"를 설명하면서 사람들 사기를 북돋우고 하나로 모이게 만드는 식이에요.
text_zh: 我经常做这样的思考实验：从这个问题出发，我会不会有冲动去解决它？对吧？不管表面上听起来多无聊，我觉得真正厉害的产品经理(product manager)都有一种魔力。他们会说："你看，这就是为什么这个问题这么要命，为什么这么有意思"，然后就把整个团队都给调动起来了。
text_es: Para mí el ejercicio mental siempre es: después de eso, ¿siento que realmente me urge trabajar en ese problema? ¿No? Por más aburrido que suene al principio, creo que un product manager realmente bueno como que le da una vuelta especial. Es tipo "Mira, por esto es tan fundamental y por esto es tan interesante", y logra motivar a todo el equipo.
context: Yuhki Yamashita, Chief Product Officer at Figma, discusses what he looks for when candidates describe big problems they've worked on. He explains that exceptional product managers have the ability to make any problem sound compelling and important through their storytelling skills, which is crucial since much of a PM's job involves communication and inspiring teams to work on challenging problems.
vocabulary_highlights: feel compelled, casts something, rallied the troops up

speaker: Jiaona Zhang
text: Good answers are people who put structure and a way forward through the ambiguity. That's what you look for. You want your PM to not just be like, "Oh no, we're swimming in ambiguity," but actually put a path forward.
text_ko: 좋은 답을 주는 사람은 애매한 상황에서도 구조를 세우고 앞으로 나아갈 길을 제시하는 사람이에요. 그게 바로 당신이 찾는 사람이고요. 프로덕트 매니저(PM)가 그냥 "아, 불확실성 속에서 허우적대고 있다"만 말하는 사람이 아니라 실제로 갈 길을 만들어 주길 원해요.
text_zh: 好的回答是那些能在不确定性中理出头绪、找到前进方向的人。这就是你要找的。你希望你的产品经理(PM)不是那种遇到模糊情况就说"完了，咱们现在一头雾水"，而是能实实在在地规划出一条路来。
text_es: Las buenas respuestas vienen de gente que logra poner estructura y trazar un camino claro en medio de toda esa incertidumbre. Eso es lo que buscas. Quieres que tu PM no se quede ahí diciendo "Ay, no, estamos perdidos en la ambigüedad," sino que realmente proponga un plan para seguir adelante.
context: JZ, Head of Product at Webflow, explains her approach to behavioral interview questions when Lenny asks about evaluating PM candidates. She emphasizes that product management is inherently ambiguous, so she tests how candidates navigate unclear situations. The best candidates don't get paralyzed by uncertainty but instead create structure and actionable plans to move forward.
vocabulary_highlights: put structure, swimming in ambiguity, put a path forward

speaker: Noah Weiss
speaker_expertise: Product Management, AI/ML Products, Product Design
text: "What unfair secrets have you learned to improve the velocity and energy level of a product team?" When I say "unfair" or "secret", I usually mean not something that you probably read on a media. "What did you learn? How did you learn it? How does it work, and how do you apply it?"
text_ko: 프로덕트 팀(product team)의 속도(velocity)와 활력(energy level)을 개선하기 위해 터득한 'unfair'한 비결이 뭐예요? 여기서 'unfair'나 'secret'이라고 하면 보통 미디어에서 볼 수 있는 평범한 얘기가 아니라, 잘 알려지지 않은 실전 노하우를 말해요. 무엇을 배웠나요? 어떻게 배웠고, 그게 어떻게 작동하며, 실제로 어떻게 적용하나요?
text_zh: "你有什么不为人知的独门绝活，能让产品团队的效率和活力大幅提升？我说的'不为人知'或者'独门绝活'，不是那种你在媒体上随便就能看到的东西。你是怎么学到的？具体怎么操作？又是怎么运用到实际工作中的？"
text_es: "¿Qué trucos o secretos no tan conocidos has aprendido para acelerar el ritmo y subir la energía de un equipo de producto? Cuando digo 'trucos' o 'secretos', me refiero a cosas que probablemente no vas a leer en cualquier artículo o blog. ¿Qué aprendiste? ¿Cómo lo aprendiste? ¿Cómo funciona y cómo lo aplicas?"
context: Noah Weiss, Chief Product Officer at Slack, shares his favorite interview question when Lenny asks about creative ways to evaluate candidates. He's looking for unique insights or unconventional methods that candidates have discovered through experience rather than from commonly available resources like blog posts or articles. This helps him identify people with genuine hands-on learning and innovative thinking.
vocabulary_highlights: unfair secrets, velocity and energy level

speaker: Nikhyl Singhal
speaker_expertise: Consumer Products, Team Building, Leadership Development
text: "What's something that everyone takes for granted that you think is essentially hogwash or inaccurate?" Sometimes I'll ask a manager, "Look, you've managed hundreds of people in your career. What's conventional wisdom that you bet against, that you have found is actually inaccurate?"
text_ko: 사람들이 다들 당연하게 여기는 것 중에 사실 본질적으로 엉터리이거나 틀렸다고 생각하는 게 뭐예요? 가끔 매니저들에게 이렇게 물어봐요. "경력 동안 수백 명을 관리해오셨잖아요. 사람들이 당연하게 믿는 통념(conventional wisdom) 중에서 당신이 반대했던, 그리고 실제로는 틀렸다고 확인된 게 뭐예요?"
text_zh: "有什么事情是大家都觉得理所当然，但你认为其实是胡扯或者不对的？"有时候我会问管理者："你看，你职业生涯中管过几百号人了，有什么所谓的传统观念(conventional wisdom)是你不认同的，觉得其实是错的？"
text_es: "¿Hay algo que todo el mundo da por sentado pero que tú consideras puras tonterías o incorrecto?" A veces le pregunto a un gerente: "Mira, has dirigido a cientos de personas en tu carrera. ¿Qué sabiduría convencional rechazas, que has comprobado que en realidad está equivocada?"
context: Nikhyl Singhal, VP of Product at Facebook, explains his strategy for breaking through typical interview responses when Lenny asks about authentic ways to evaluate candidates. This question forces people to share genuine opinions and challenge widely accepted beliefs, helping him assess whether candidates can think independently and avoid giving rehearsed answers that don't reveal their true thinking.
vocabulary_highlights: takes for granted, essentially hogwash, conventional wisdom, bet against

speaker: Itamar Gilad
text: You fake it, you do a fake door test, you do a smoke test, Wizard of Oz tests. We used a lot of those in the tabbed inbox by the way, one of the first early versions was actually we showed the tabbed inbox working to people. But it wasn't really Gmail, it was just a facade of HTML and behind the scenes and according to the permissions that the users gave us some of us moved just the subject and the sender into the right place.
text_ko: 일단 흉내를 내요. 페이크 도어 테스트(fake door test), 스모크 테스트(smoke test), 위자드 오브 오즈 테스트(Wizard of Oz test) 같은 걸 해요. 참고로 탭형 인박스(tabbed inbox) 만들 때 그런 방식을 많이 썼어요. 초기 버전 중 하나는 탭형 인박스가 실제로 작동하는 것처럼 사람들한테 보여주는 거였어요. 근데 그게 진짜 Gmail이 작동하는 건 아니고, 단지 HTML(HTML)로 만든 겉모습(facade)뿐이었어요. 내부적으로는 사용자들이 준 권한(permissions)에 따라 제목(subject)과 발신자(sender) 정보만 옮겨서 적절한 곳에 배치했어요.
text_zh: 你先造个假的，做个假门测试(fake door test)，做个冒烟测试(smoke test)，还有绿野仙踪测试(Wizard of Oz test)。我们在标签收件箱那个项目里就大量用了这些方法，最早的一个版本其实就是我们给用户演示标签收件箱的功能。但那根本不是真的Gmail，就是个HTML的壳子，后台我们根据用户给的权限，手动把邮件主题和发件人挪到对应的位置。
text_es: Lo simulas, haces una prueba de puerta falsa (fake door test), haces una prueba de humo (smoke test), pruebas del Mago de Oz (Wizard of Oz tests). De hecho usamos muchas de esas técnicas en la bandeja de entrada con pestañas, una de las primeras versiones en realidad consistía en mostrarle a la gente cómo funcionaba la bandeja con pestañas. Pero no era realmente Gmail, era solo una fachada de HTML y por detrás, según los permisos que nos daban los usuarios, algunos de nosotros simplemente movíamos el asunto y el remitente al lugar correcto.
context: Lenny asks Itamar about methods for testing product ideas before building them. Itamar explains various low-cost validation techniques including fake door tests, smoke tests, and Wizard of Oz tests - methods where you simulate a working product without actually building the real functionality. He shares how his team at Google used this approach when developing Gmail's tabbed inbox feature, creating an HTML facade that manually sorted messages to test user reactions before writing any actual code.
vocabulary_highlights: fake door test, smoke test, Wizard of Oz tests, facade of HTML

speaker: Itamar Gilad
text: Google+ was my first experience at Gmail, I joined Gmail in August 2011 and the first thing they asked me is, "Let's connect Gmail with Google+." If you're hazy about the story, back then Facebook was massive. It's still massive but then it was growing like mushrooms, people were spending hours. That really freaked out Google and the obvious solution was to launch a social network of Google called Google+ and we all believe in this thing, it really caught on very well initially we all used it, we all believed in it.
text_ko: 구글플러스(Google+)가 제 지메일(Gmail)에서의 첫 경험이었어요. 저는 2011년 8월에 지메일에 합류했는데, 첫 말이 “지메일을 구글플러스와 연결하자”였어요. 이야기가 잘 안 떠오르면 당시 페이스북(Facebook)이 엄청났다는 걸 기억하시면 돼요. 지금도 크지만 그때는 마치 버섯처럼 폭발적으로 성장해서 사람들이 몇 시간씩 그 안에 머물렀죠. 그게 구글을 정말 긴장하게 만들었고, 당연한 해법은 구글의 소셜 네트워크인 구글플러스(Google+)를 내놓는 거였어요. 우리도 다들 그걸 믿었고 초반에는 반응도 좋아서 모두가 사용했어요.
text_zh: 我在Google+的经历其实是我在Gmail的第一次体验，我2011年8月加入Gmail，他们给我的第一个任务就是"把Gmail和Google+连起来"。如果你对当时的情况不太清楚的话，那时候Facebook特别火，现在也很火，但当时真的是疯狂增长，用户一泡就是好几个小时。这把Google吓得不轻，最明显的解决办法就是推出Google自己的社交网络，也就是Google+。我们所有人都对这个产品很有信心，刚开始确实挺成功的，我们都在用，也都很看好它。
text_es: Google+ fue mi primera experiencia en Gmail, me uní a Gmail en agosto de 2011 y lo primero que me pidieron fue: "Vamos a conectar Gmail con Google+." Si no tienes claro el panorama, en esa época Facebook era enorme. Sigue siendo enorme pero en ese entonces estaba creciendo como la espuma, la gente se pasaba horas ahí. Eso realmente puso nervioso a Google y la solución obvia era lanzar una red social de Google llamada Google+ y todos creíamos en esto, realmente pegó muy bien al principio, todos la usábamos, todos creíamos en ella.
context: Lenny asks Itamar to share the story of his work on Google+ and Gmail that shaped his product development philosophy. Itamar explains that when he joined Gmail in 2011, his first assignment was integrating Gmail with Google+, Google's new social network created in response to Facebook's rapid growth. He describes how Facebook's success 'freaked out' Google leadership, leading them to launch their own social platform that initially seemed promising within the company.
vocabulary_highlights: hazy about the story, growing like mushrooms, freaked out, caught on very well

speaker: Itamar Gilad
text: So putting aside all the tremendous waste that went into this, all the millions of person hours and personal weeks. In hindsight, not only did Google bet on the wrong thing it missed much easier opportunities. So just not far from Google's headquarters there was WhatsApp, not very famous in the US but they actually created massive impact. Hundreds of millions of people were using their stuff and they became a threat to Facebook much more than Google was.
text_ko: 그 모든 엄청난 낭비—수백만 인시(person-hours)와 수천 인주(person-weeks)를 제쳐두고 보면, 돌이켜 보면 구글은 잘못된 것에 베팅했을 뿐 아니라 훨씬 더 쉬운 기회들도 놓쳤어요. 구글 본사 근처에 WhatsApp이 있었는데, 미국에선 그렇게 유명하진 않았지만 실제로는 엄청난 영향력을 만들었어요. 수억 명이 그 서비스를 사용했고, 그들은 구글보다 오히려 페이스북에게 더 큰 위협이 되었어요.
text_zh: 先不说这里面浪费了多少资源，投入了多少人力和时间。现在回头看，谷歌不仅押错了宝，还错过了更容易抓住的机会。就在谷歌总部不远的地方有个WhatsApp，在美国可能不太出名，但人家确实做出了巨大影响。几亿人在用他们的产品，对Facebook的威胁比谷歌大多了。
text_es: Entonces, dejando de lado todo el tremendo desperdicio que hubo en esto, todos esos millones de horas-persona y semanas de trabajo. Viendo las cosas ahora, no solo Google apostó por lo que no era, sino que se perdió oportunidades mucho más fáciles. Mira, ahí nomás cerca de las oficinas de Google estaba WhatsApp, que no era muy conocido en Estados Unidos pero que realmente creó un impacto enorme. Cientos de millones de personas usaban su plataforma y se convirtieron en una amenaza para Facebook mucho mayor de lo que Google jamás fue.
context: Lenny asks about the scale of resources invested in the Google+ project. Itamar reflects on the massive waste of resources - millions of person hours - that Google+ represented when it ultimately failed. He points out the irony that while Google was building a Facebook competitor, WhatsApp (located near Google's headquarters) was creating a much more successful social product that actually threatened Facebook, representing the kind of opportunity Google missed by focusing on the wrong approach.
vocabulary_highlights: putting aside, tremendous waste, bet on the wrong thing, not far from

speaker: Itamar Gilad
text: So for me, this story kind of was the epitome of what I call today, opinion-based development. We come up with an idea, we believe in it, all the indications show it's good. Maybe the early tests show it's good, then we just go all in and we try to implement it and I made this very mistake many times as the product manager, I was the guy pushing for the ideas.
text_ko: 저에게 이 이야기는 제가 요즘 '의견 기반 개발(opinion-based development)'이라고 부르는 방식의 전형이었어요. 아이디어가 떠오르면 우리가 그걸 믿고, 모든 지표가 괜찮게 보이면—초기 테스트에서도 괜찮게 나오면—그냥 올인해서 구현하려고 해요. 제품 매니저로 일할 때 저도 그런 실수를 여러 번 했어요. 아이디어를 밀어붙이던 사람이 바로 저였거든요.
text_zh: 对我来说，这个故事就是我现在说的"观点驱动开发(opinion-based development)"的典型例子。我们想出一个点子，觉得肯定行，各种迹象都显示不错，可能早期测试也挺好的，然后我们就全力以赴去做，拼命想把它落地。我当产品经理的时候就经常犯这种错误，我就是那个一个劲儿推想法的人。
text_es: Entonces para mí, esta historia fue como el ejemplo perfecto de lo que hoy llamo desarrollo basado en opiniones (opinion-based development). Se nos ocurre una idea, creemos en ella, todas las señales indican que está buena. A lo mejor las primeras pruebas salen bien, y entonces nos lanzamos de lleno a implementarla. Y yo cometí este mismo error muchas veces como product manager, yo era el que empujaba las ideas.
context: Lenny asks Itamar about lessons learned from the Google+ experience. Itamar explains how Google+ became the perfect example of 'opinion-based development' - a flawed approach where teams become overly confident in their ideas based on limited evidence and then commit massive resources without proper validation. He admits his own role in perpetuating this mistake as a product manager who enthusiastically championed ideas without sufficient evidence.
vocabulary_highlights: epitome of, opinion-based development, go all in, pushing for the ideas
topics: Product Management, Decision Making, Learning & Growth

speaker: Itamar Gilad
text: So that sent us, kind of me and my team into researching these users into establishing a goal that was much more user-centric and then thinking of other ideas. And then we started testing them much more rigorously and basically we started testing on our own inboxes and then we recruited other dog footers, other Googlers to test the same inbox, then we put it outside for external testers.
text_ko: 그래서 저랑 제 팀은 그 사용자들을 조사하고 훨씬 사용자 중심적인 목표를 세우는 쪽으로 움직였어요. 그러면서 다른 아이디어들도 생각해보고, 그 아이디어들을 훨씬 더 엄격하게 테스트하기 시작했죠. 일단 우리 각자의 인박스(inbox)에서 먼저 해봤고, 그다음 사내 도그푸딩(dogfooding)에 참여한 다른 구글러들(Googlers)에게도 같은 인박스를 테스트하게 했어요. 이후에는 외부 테스터들(external testers)에게도 공개했어요.
text_zh: 这就让我们，也就是我和我的团队，开始深入研究这些用户，制定了一个更加以用户为中心的目标，然后想出了其他一些想法。接着我们开始更严格地测试这些想法，基本上我们先在自己的邮箱里测试，然后招募其他dog footer，也就是其他谷歌员工来测试同样的邮箱功能，最后我们把它放到外部给外部测试人员使用。
text_es: Entonces eso nos llevó, tanto a mí como a mi equipo, a investigar más a fondo a estos usuarios, a establecer un objetivo que fuera mucho más centrado en el usuario y después pensar en otras ideas. Y ahí empezamos a hacer pruebas mucho más rigurosas - básicamente comenzamos probando en nuestros propios correos y luego reclutamos a otros dog footers, otros Googlers para que probaran la misma bandeja de entrada, y después lo sacamos afuera para probadores externos.
context: Lenny asks about the contrasting approach used for Gmail's tabbed inbox feature. Itamar describes how skeptical feedback from colleagues forced his team to adopt a more evidence-based approach. Instead of immediately building their idea, they researched users more deeply, established user-centric goals, and implemented rigorous testing methods - starting with their own inboxes, then expanding to other Google employees (called 'dog fooders' in tech parlance), and finally external users.
vocabulary_highlights: sent us into, user-centric, more rigorously, dog footers
topics: Product Management, Strategy & Planning, Learning & Growth

speaker: Itamar Gilad
text: I think the founders are very important, especially in the startup and scale-ups phase. They come up with many of the most important ideas and it's super important that they have the space to express and to push the organization to look at those. However, it's not about shutting them down it's about looking at them critically.
text_ko: 창업자들(founders)은 정말 중요해요, 특히 스타트업과 스케일업 단계(startup and scale-ups phase)에서요. 많은 핵심 아이디어들이 창업자들로부터 나오니까, 그들이 아이디어를 말하고 조직이 그걸 검토해볼 수 있게 공간을 주는 게 엄청 중요해요. 다만 그들을 무조건 막아버리는 게 아니라, 그 아이디어들을 비판적으로 살펴보는 게 중요한 거예요.
text_zh: 我觉得创始人特别重要，尤其是在创业和扩张阶段。很多最核心的想法都是他们想出来的，所以一定要给他们空间去表达，去推动公司关注这些想法。但这不是说要完全否定他们，而是要批判性地看待这些想法。
text_es: Creo que los fundadores son fundamentales, sobre todo en la fase de startup y cuando estás escalando. Se les ocurren muchas de las ideas más importantes y es clave que tengan el espacio para expresarlas y empujar a la organización a considerarlas. Pero ojo, no se trata de cortarles las alas, sino de analizar esas ideas con sentido crítico.
context: Lenny asks whether there are instances where opinion-based approaches make sense, particularly with visionary founders like Steve Jobs. Itamar clarifies that founders play a crucial role in generating important ideas, especially in startups and scale-ups, and should have space to express their vision. However, he emphasizes that the solution isn't to shut down founder ideas but rather to examine them critically with evidence rather than blindly executing them.
vocabulary_highlights: scale-ups phase, push the organization, shutting them down, looking at them critically
topics: Leadership & Management, Starting a Company, Decision Making

speaker: Itamar Gilad
text: I think there's a few telltale signs that I look for, first the goals are very unclear. Either there are many or they're very kind of obscure and vague or they are about output, there's misalignment. So the goals part is not there, usually this goes hand in hand with metrics. Missing metrics or just using revenue and business metric but there's no user facing metrics.
text_ko: 제가 보는 몇 가지 대표적인 징후가 있어요. 먼저 목표가 굉장히 불명확해요. 목표가 너무 많거나 애매모호하거나, 산출물(output) 위주라서 정렬이 안 돼 있는 경우가 많아요. 즉 목표 자체가 제대로 잡혀 있지 않은 거죠. 보통 이런 문제는 지표(metrics)와 함께 나타나요. 지표가 아예 없거나 매출(revenue)이나 비즈니스 지표(business metric)만 보고 사용자 지향 지표(user-facing metrics)는 전혀 안 보는 식이에요.
text_zh: 我觉得有几个明显的征象，首先就是目标特别不清楚。要么目标太多，要么就是很模糊很含糊，或者都是围绕产出的，整个就是不匹配的。所以目标这块就有问题，通常这和指标也是连在一起的。要么就是缺指标，要么就只看营收和业务指标，但是没有面向用户的指标。
text_es: Yo creo que hay varias señales que siempre busco. Primero, los objetivos están súper confusos - o hay demasiados, o están muy vagos y poco claros, o se enfocan solo en resultados sin alineación real. Entonces esa parte de los objetivos no está funcionando, y esto normalmente va de la mano con las métricas. Te das cuenta que faltan métricas o solo están usando ingresos y métricas de negocio, pero no hay métricas que miren al usuario.
context: Lenny asks what signs indicate that a company isn't as evidence-guided as they think they are. Itamar identifies several telltale signs of poor evidence-guided practices: unclear, numerous, or vague goals that focus on outputs rather than outcomes, misalignment across teams, and inadequate metrics - particularly the absence of user-facing metrics while only tracking business metrics like revenue.
vocabulary_highlights: telltale signs, obscure and vague, goes hand in hand, user facing metrics
topics: Product Management, Strategy & Planning, Leadership & Management

speaker: Ivan Zhao
speaker_expertise: B2B SaaS, Product Design, Career Development
text: We try many different versions. The first version, okay, everybody can make and create their software, so let's just build a developer tool that's so easy that more people can do that. We tried that a couple of years and learned that actually most people just don't care. Our realization is actually let's hide our vision, which is everybody can create their software in the form factor that people do care.
text_ko: 저희는 여러 가지 버전을 시도해봤어요. 첫 버전에는 ‘모두가 자신만의 소프트웨어를 만들 수 있으니까, 더 많은 사람이 할 수 있게 아주 쉬운 개발자 도구(developer tool)를 만들자’고 했죠. 그걸 몇 년 해봤는데 사실 대부분의 사람들은 별로 관심이 없더라고요. 그래서 깨달은 건, ‘누구나 자신만의 소프트웨어를 만들 수 있다’는 우리 비전을 겉으로 내세우기보다는 사람들이 진짜로 신경 쓰는 폼팩터(form factor) 속에 숨겨 담아내자는 거였어요.
text_zh: 我们试了很多不同的版本。第一个版本，就是说，好吧，每个人都应该能做软件，那我们就做一个超简单的开发工具(developer tool)，让更多人都能上手。我们试了好几年，后来发现其实大部分人根本不在乎这个。我们的感悟就是，其实应该把我们的愿景包装一下，就是"人人都能做软件"这个理念，要用大家真正关心的方式来呈现。
text_es: Probamos muchas versiones diferentes. La primera versión, bueno, todo el mundo puede crear su propio software, entonces dijimos "vamos a crear una herramienta para desarrolladores que sea tan fácil que más gente pueda hacerlo." Lo intentamos un par de años y nos dimos cuenta de que en realidad a la mayoría de la gente le da igual. Lo que descubrimos es que en vez de mostrar nuestra visión directamente - que todo el mundo pueda crear su software - mejor la presentamos de una forma que sí le importe a la gente.
context: Lenny asks Ivan about the early years of Notion, which Ivan describes as 'the lost years' - the first three to four years when they struggled to find product-market fit. Ivan explains how they initially tried to build a developer tool that would let everyone create software, but discovered most people simply weren't interested in that approach. The key insight was realizing they needed to hide their ambitious vision behind something people already understood and used daily.
vocabulary_highlights: form factor, hide our vision

speaker: Ivan Zhao
speaker_expertise: B2B SaaS, Product Design, Career Development
text: We called it sugar-coated broccoli. People don't want to eat the broccoli but people like sugar, so it gave them the sugar then hide your broccoli inside of it.
text_ko: 우리는 그걸 '설탕 입힌 브로콜리(sugar-coated broccoli)'라고 불렀어요. 사람들은 브로콜리를 먹고 싶어 하지 않지만 달콤한 건 좋아하니까, 설탕으로 코팅해서 달콤함을 먼저 주고 그 안에 브로콜리를 숨겨 넣었어요.
text_zh: 我们叫它"糖衣西兰花"。大家都不爱吃西兰花，但都喜欢糖，所以就先给他们糖，然后把西兰花藏在里面。
text_es: Le decíamos brócoli con azúcar. A la gente no le gusta comerse el brócoli, pero el azúcar sí les gusta, entonces les das el azúcar y escondes el brócoli adentro.
context: Ivan continues explaining Notion's strategy for making their developer-focused vision more accessible to regular users. After realizing people didn't care about creating software tools, they decided to package their powerful capabilities inside familiar productivity software that people already knew they needed. This metaphor captures how they made their complex, technical vision palatable by wrapping it in something people already wanted.
vocabulary_highlights: sugar-coated broccoli

speaker: Ivan Zhao
speaker_expertise: B2B SaaS, Product Design, Career Development
text: What is the building a product or business. You want user. You want revenue. That's the product business. And building for something you want the world to have is building for your value. You have some taste. You have some aesthetic. There are different energy. You need to create a balance. Too much of yourself. Then there's no users. Then you're just doing our project. And too much for business, you're building a commodity.
text_ko: 제품(product)이나 비즈니스(business)를 만든다는 건 결국 사용자(users)를 원하고 수익(revenue)을 원한다는 뜻이에요. 그게 바로 프로덕트 비즈니스(product business)이죠. 반면에 세상 사람들이 꼭 갖길 바라는 무언가를 만들 때는 당신의 가치(value)를 담아 만드는 거예요 — 취향(taste)이나 미적 감각(aesthetic), 그리고 다른 에너지가 들어가죠. 그래서 둘 사이의 균형을 만들어야 해요. 너무 자신만의 색을 내면 사용자가 없어서 그냥 개인 프로젝트일 뿐이고, 반대로 비즈니스 쪽으로만 치우치면 커머디티(commodity)가 돼 버려요.
text_zh: 做产品做生意吧，你肯定想要用户，想要收入，这就是产品生意。但如果你做的是你希望这个世界拥有的东西，那就是在做你的价值观。你有自己的品味，有自己的审美，这是完全不同的能量。你得找到平衡点。太注重自己的想法，就没用户了，那就变成自己玩了。太偏向商业，你做出来的就是个大路货。
text_es: Mira, cuando estás construyendo un producto o negocio, quieres usuarios. Quieres ingresos. Eso es el negocio del producto. Pero construir algo que quieres que el mundo tenga, eso es construir según tus valores. Tienes cierto gusto. Tienes cierta estética. Son energías diferentes. Necesitas crear un equilibrio. Si te enfocas demasiado en ti mismo, entonces no hay usuarios. Entonces solo estás haciendo tu proyecto personal. Y si te enfocas demasiado en el negocio, estás construyendo una commodity (producto básico).
context: Lenny asks Ivan about key elements for finding something that works after years of struggle. Ivan explains the fundamental tension in building products - balancing what the market wants (users and revenue) versus what you personally believe the world needs (your values and vision). He describes this as managing different types of energy and warns against going too far in either direction.
vocabulary_highlights: building a commodity

speaker: Ivan Zhao
speaker_expertise: B2B SaaS, Product Design, Career Development
text: I think going back to the abstraction system way of problem solving, I think we're lucky that me and Simon and Akshay, we have the skillset you probably can run a whole company, which is a couple of us, I can design, I can do marketing, storytelling, close sales deals. So you realize you don't need a lot. But when you can do a lot at the same time or hire people who can do that, naturally keep the company small.
text_ko: 다시 문제를 추상화해서 푸는 방식(abstraction system way of problem solving)으로 돌아가 보면, 저랑 사이먼, 악샤이 셋이서 회사 하나를 운영할 수 있는 스킬셋(skillset)을 가진 건 운이 좋은 일이에요. 저는 디자인도 하고, 마케팅(marketing)과 스토리텔링(storytelling)을 하고, 영업 딜을 성사시키는 역할까지 할 수 있으니까요. 그래서 많은 사람이 필요 없다는 걸 금방 깨닫게 돼요. 한 사람이 여러 역할을 동시에 소화할 수 있거나 그런 사람들을 채용할 수 있다면 자연스럽게 회사를 작게 유지하게 돼요.
text_zh: 我觉得回到抽象化系统(abstraction system)解决问题的方式，我们挺幸运的，我、Simon还有Akshay，我们几个人的技能组合基本上就能撑起整个公司。我能搞设计、做营销、讲故事、谈成销售。你会发现其实不需要太多人。但是当你自己能身兼数职，或者招到这样的多面手时，公司自然就能保持精简。
text_es: Mira, volviendo al tema de resolver problemas con sistemas de abstracción, creo que tenemos mucha suerte Simon, Akshay y yo, porque tenemos las habilidades para prácticamente manejar toda una empresa entre unos pocos. Yo puedo hacer diseño, marketing, contar historias, cerrar ventas. Entonces te das cuenta de que no necesitas tanto. Pero cuando puedes hacer muchas cosas a la vez o contratar gente que también sea versátil, naturalmente mantienes la empresa chiquita.
context: Lenny asks Ivan why Notion has stayed remarkably lean and efficient compared to other companies of their scale - they're profitable, didn't hire a salesperson until 10M ARR, and kept their team very small. Ivan explains their approach centers on hiring versatile people who can handle multiple functions rather than specialists, and using better systems and tools (including Notion itself) to solve problems instead of throwing more people at them.
vocabulary_highlights: abstraction system way of problem solving, run a whole company

speaker: Ivan Zhao
speaker_expertise: B2B SaaS, Product Design, Career Development
text: We internally help other people and understand this. Internally we use the metaphor that Notion's a small bus. The bus, the smaller the bus, it's easier to turn corners, easier to accelerate, easier to maneuver. The bigger the bus it is, bigger the boat or bigger the bus, slow down. And as a leader in the company, you decide who sit around you on the bus seats.
text_ko: 우리는 내부적으로 서로 도와주고 그걸 잘 이해하고 있어요. 사내에서는 Notion을 작은 버스에 비유해요. 버스는 작을수록 코너 돌기도 쉽고 가속도 잘 되고 조작하기도 쉬워요. 반대로 버스나 배가 커지면 속도가 느려지고 움직이기 어렵죠. 회사에서 리더로서 버스 좌석에 누가 앉을지는 리더가 결정해요.
text_zh: 我们内部会互相帮助，大家都明白这个道理。在内部我们有个比喻，说Notion就像一辆小巴士。巴士越小，转弯越灵活，加速越快，操控起来也越容易。巴士越大，不管是大船还是大巴，都会变慢。作为公司的领导者，你要决定谁能坐在你身边的座位上。
text_es: Internamente ayudamos a otros y entendemos esto. Dentro de la empresa usamos la metáfora de que Notion es como un autobús pequeño. Entre más pequeño sea el autobús, más fácil es tomar las curvas, acelerar más rápido, maniobrar mejor. Entre más grande sea el autobús, o el barco, o lo que sea, más lento va todo. Y como líder de la empresa, tú decides quién se sienta a tu lado en los asientos del autobús.
context: Lenny asks Ivan for advice on how to actually stay lean when it's tempting to hire more engineers and designers. Ivan shares an internal metaphor they use at Notion to help employees understand why staying small is advantageous. He explains that like vehicles, smaller organizations can change direction and move faster, while larger ones become harder to steer and slower to respond to market changes.
vocabulary_highlights: turn corners, maneuver

speaker: Ivan Zhao
speaker_expertise: B2B SaaS, Product Design, Career Development
text: I think just understand abstraction or system is a better curve than pecan curve, right? Linear. We internally help other people and understand this... I think the more interesting point here, it's like you can create progress through better abstractions. And that thing compounds faster, can catch up to all the things you build much quicker than you ever thought.
text_ko: 제 생각에는 추상화(abstraction)나 시스템(system)을 이해하는 게 피칸 커브(pecan curve)보다 더 나은 곡선이라고 생각해요 — 선형(linear)이죠. 저희는 내부적으로 다른 사람들을 도와가며 이걸 이해하고요. 더 흥미로운 점은, 더 나은 추상화(abstraction)를 통해 진전을 만들어낼 수 있다는 거예요. 그 효과가 복리(compounding)처럼 더 빠르게 불어나서, 여러분이 만든 모든 것들을 생각보다 훨씬 빨리 따라잡을 수 있어요.
text_zh: 我觉得理解抽象概念或者系统架构，这个学习曲线比那种复杂曲线要好走得多，对吧？比较直线型的。我们内部也会帮助其他人理解这些东西...我觉得更有意思的是，你可以通过更好的抽象思维来推动进步。这种东西的复利效应特别快，能够追上你之前搭建的所有东西，速度比你想象的要快得多。
text_es: Mira, creo que entender la abstracción o el sistema te da una curva de aprendizaje mucho mejor que la curva exponencial, ¿no? Es más lineal. Internamente ayudamos a otros a entender esto... Creo que lo más interesante aquí es que puedes generar progreso a través de mejores abstracciones. Y eso se potencia mucho más rápido, puede alcanzar todo lo que construyes mucho más rápido de lo que jamás pensaste.
context: Ivan is explaining why he advocates for not being afraid to reset and start over when building products. He argues that humans think linearly, but finding better abstractions or fundamental approaches can create exponential progress. This means that even if you throw away previous work to build on better foundations, you can recover that lost progress much faster than expected because the new approach compounds more effectively.
vocabulary_highlights: better curve than pecan curve, compounds faster, catch up to all the things you build

speaker: Jackie Bavaro
speaker_expertise: Product Strategy, Product Management, Career Development
text: I had this belief that almost anybody can learn anything. People have different interests, not everybody wants to learn everything. But I find that if you're having trouble learning something, it's just because something's not clicking. There's just something that you're misunderstanding or that other people see that you're not seeing. And if people could just describe it in the way that matched YOUR mental model, then you could learn it.
text_ko: 저는 거의 누구나 무엇이든 배울 수 있다고 믿어요. 사람들마다 관심사가 다르고 모든 사람이 다 모든 걸 배우고 싶어하는 건 아니에요. 그런데 뭔가를 배우는 데 어려움을 겪는다면 그건 그냥 뭔가가 딱 안 맞아서예요. 본인이 오해하고 있거나 다른 사람들이 보는 걸 못 보고 있는 부분이 있는 거죠. 다른 사람들이 그걸 당신의 멘탈 모델(mental model)에 맞게 설명해 주기만 하면 배울 수 있어요.
text_zh: 我一直相信一个道理，几乎所有人都能学会任何东西。当然了，每个人兴趣不一样，也不是人人都想学所有的东西。但我发现，如果你觉得某样东西怎么都学不会，那肯定是哪里没开窍。肯定有什么地方你理解错了，或者别人看明白的东西你还没看透。如果有人能用符合你思维方式的方法来解释，你绝对能学会。
text_es: Siempre he creído que casi cualquier persona puede aprender lo que sea. La gente tiene intereses diferentes, no todo el mundo quiere aprender de todo. Pero me he dado cuenta de que si te está costando trabajo aprender algo, es simplemente porque algo no te está haciendo "clic". Hay algo que no estás captando bien o que otros ven pero tú no logras ver. Y si la gente pudiera explicártelo de una manera que encaje con TU forma de pensar, entonces sí lo podrías aprender.
context: Lenny asks Jackie about her motivation for writing her product management books. Jackie explains her philosophy on learning, which drove her to write accessible guides for PM interviews. She believes that when people struggle to learn something, it's usually because the information isn't being presented in a way that matches their mental framework, rather than an inability to understand the concept itself.
vocabulary_highlights: something's not clicking, mental model

speaker: Jackie Bavaro
speaker_expertise: Product Strategy, Product Management, Career Development
text: I very much saw the PM's role is a person who wants to say no to everybody. I was like, 'All these people want us to do stuff and we would do way too much and we would never get anything important done if we just said yes to them. I need to say no to people.' And I got into this defensive mindset and sometimes people would come to me with ideas and I'd be like, 'Are you telling me I can't do my job right?' And I would just try to say no to them as efficiently and effectively as possible.
text_ko: 저는 프로덕트 매니저(PM)의 역할을 거의 '모든 사람에게 아니라고 말해야 하는 사람'이라고 생각했어요. 사람들이 우리한테 이것저것 해 달라고 하면, 전부 다 받아주면 우리가 할 일이 너무 많아져서 정작 중요한 건 하나도 못 하게 될 거라고 생각했죠. 그래서 사람들에게 아니라고 말해야 한다고요. 그렇게 방어적인 마음가짐이 됐고, 사람들이 아이디어를 들고 오면 저는 '제가 제 일을 제대로 못한다는 말이에요?'라고 느끼곤 했어요. 그래서 가능한 한 효율적이고 효과적으로 거절하려고만 했어요.
text_zh: 我当时觉得产品经理(PM)的职责就是要对所有人说"不"。我想着，"这么多人都想让我们做这做那，如果我们都答应的话，肯定会摊子铺得太大，真正重要的事情反而做不成。我得学会拒绝。"然后我就陷入了一种防御心理，有时候别人来找我提想法，我就会想"你这是在说我不会干活吗？"我就想着怎么能最快最有效地把他们拒绝掉。
text_es: Yo veía el rol del PM como alguien que tiene que decirle que no a todo el mundo. Pensaba: 'Toda esta gente quiere que hagamos cosas y acabaríamos haciendo demasiado, nunca terminaríamos nada importante si les dijéramos que sí a todos. Tengo que decir que no.' Y me puse súper defensivo, a veces la gente venía con ideas y yo reaccionaba como '¿Me estás diciendo que no sé hacer mi trabajo?' Y básicamente trataba de decirles que no de la manera más rápida y efectiva posible.
context: Lenny asks Jackie about mistakes she made early in her career at Asana. Jackie describes how she initially misunderstood the PM role as being a gatekeeper who needed to reject ideas to maintain focus. This defensive approach backfired when she shut down her boss's suggestion, leading to a pivotal learning moment about the importance of collaboration over control in product management.
vocabulary_highlights: defensive mindset, efficiently and effectively as possible
topics: Product Management, Leadership & Management, Communication Skills

speaker: Jackie Bavaro
speaker_expertise: Product Strategy, Product Management, Career Development
text: For the next two weeks, say yes to everything. I think you can find a way to do your job and still say yes to people. You can say, 'yes, I agree. That is a real problem. Yes. I think we could test this design with users' and just see what's different with two weeks of saying yes to people instead of no. And I realized that this protectiveness and lockdownness that I had really wasn't something I needed and it wasn't something that was serving me because it meant that I couldn't have real collaboration with the other people around me.
text_ko: 다음 2주 동안은 모든 것에 '네'라고 해보세요. 일을 하면서도 사람들에게 '네'라고 할 방법은 찾을 수 있을 거예요. 예를 들어 '네, 동의해요. 그건 진짜 문제네요. 네. 이 디자인을 사용자 대상으로 테스트해볼 수 있을 것 같아요'라고 말해보고, 2주 동안 '아니요' 대신 '네'라고 했을 때 뭐가 달라지는지 지켜보세요. 그걸 해보면서 제가 가지고 있던 그런 보호적이고 폐쇄적인 태도는 사실 필요 없고 저에게도 도움이 되지 않는다는 걸 깨달았어요. 그런 태도 때문에 주변 사람들과 진짜 협업을 할 수가 없었거든요.
text_zh: 接下来两周，不管什么事都先说"行"。我觉得你完全可以把工作做好的同时，也对别人说"行"。你可以说，"行，我同意。这确实是个问题。没错。我觉得我们可以让用户测试一下这个设计"，就试试看连续两周对别人说"行"而不是"不行"会有什么不一样。后来我意识到，我之前那种防御心理，什么都要把控的心态，其实根本没必要，对我也没好处，因为这样我就没法跟身边的人真正协作了。
text_es: Durante las próximas dos semanas, di que sí a todo. Creo que puedes encontrar la manera de hacer tu trabajo y aún así decirle que sí a la gente. Puedes decir: "sí, estoy de acuerdo. Ese es un problema real. Sí. Creo que podríamos probar este diseño con usuarios" y simplemente ver qué cambia con dos semanas diciéndole que sí a la gente en lugar de que no. Y me di cuenta de que esa actitud tan protectora y cerrada que tenía realmente no era algo que necesitara y no me estaba sirviendo de nada porque significaba que no podía tener una verdadera colaboración con las otras personas a mi alrededor.
context: Jackie continues explaining how her coach helped her overcome her tendency to immediately reject ideas from colleagues. The coach challenged her to spend two weeks saying yes instead of no, which taught Jackie that she could maintain her PM responsibilities while being more collaborative. This experience showed her that being overly protective of the product roadmap was actually hindering effective teamwork.
vocabulary_highlights: protectiveness and lockdownness, wasn't serving me, real collaboration
topics: Coaching & Development, Communication Skills, Leadership & Management

speaker: Jackie Bavaro
speaker_expertise: Product Strategy, Product Management, Career Development
text: I worked with her for several months, but then once that was gone, then I did start to find that personally I would make things bigger when I had a coach, because I had something that I knew how to solve on my own. And I'd bring it to the coach, and then all of a sudden it felt like it was a big deal rather than a little deal. I've gone in and out of coaching, but I do it when I have a thing that I want to work on.
text_ko: 그분과 몇 달 동안 함께 일했어요. 그게 끝나고 나서는 개인적으로 코치가 있을 때 사소한 걸 더 크게 만드는 경향이 있더라고요. 혼자서 해결할 수 있는 걸 코치에게 가져가면 갑자기 그게 작은 일이 아니라 큰일인 것처럼 느껴졌어요. 코칭은 받다 말다 했는데, 다만 제가 집중해서 해결하고 싶은 일이 있을 때만 다시 받는 편이에요.
text_zh: 我跟她合作了好几个月，但后来没有教练了，我发现我个人会把事情想得更复杂。本来是我自己能解决的问题，一带到教练那里，突然感觉变成了大事，而不是小事了。我断断续续地接受过coaching，但现在只有在遇到特别想解决的问题时才会去找教练。
text_es: Trabajé con ella varios meses, pero después cuando ya no estaba, me di cuenta de que personalmente tendía a hacer más grandes los problemas cuando tenía coach, porque tenía algo que yo sabía resolver solo. Se lo llevaba al coach y de repente se sentía como algo súper importante en lugar de algo menor. He entrado y salido del coaching, pero lo hago cuando tengo algo específico en lo que quiero trabajar.
context: Lenny asks Jackie about her experience with coaching and advice for PMs considering getting a coach. Jackie explains her personal approach to coaching - she prefers working with coaches when she has specific issues to address rather than ongoing general coaching. She discovered that bringing small problems to a coach sometimes made them feel unnecessarily magnified, so she uses coaching strategically for targeted skill development.
vocabulary_highlights: make things bigger, all of a sudden, gone in and out of

speaker: Jackie Bavaro
speaker_expertise: Product Strategy, Product Management, Career Development
text: After a little bit of that, I was like, 'It might be easier if I just go, I might be able save you some time and some energy if I just joined you.' And it was a way that I took myself into this higher level meeting, framing it as something that was going to help out my boss. And it did. It wasn't dishonest, but it was a pretty effective way of advocating to get into this meeting.
text_ko: 그걸 좀 해보다가 저는 '내가 그냥 같이 가면 더 쉬울 것 같고, 그러면 네 시간하고 에너지도 좀 절약될 텐데'라고 생각했어요. 그렇게 스스로를 포지셔닝해서 더 높은 수준의 회의에 들어갈 명분을 만든 거예요—상사를 돕는다는 명목으로요. 실제로 효과가 있었어요. 정직하지 않은 건 아니었지만, 미팅에 들어가기 위해 자신을 어필하는 꽤 효과적인 방법이었어요.
text_zh: 后来我就想，"要不我直接参加吧，这样可能更简单，我加入进来可能还能帮你们节省点时间和精力。" 我就是这样把自己弄进了这个高层会议，表面上说是要帮老板的忙。确实也起到作用了。这么做不算不诚实，但确实是个很有效的方式，让我成功混进了这个会议。
text_es: Después de un rato de eso, me dije, 'Oye, tal vez sería más fácil si voy yo, capaz que les ahorro tiempo y energía si me uno a ustedes.' Y fue la manera en que me colé a esta reunión de alto nivel, presentándolo como algo que iba a ayudar a mi jefe. Y sí funcionó. No fue deshonesto, pero fue una forma bastante efectiva de abrirme paso para entrar a esa reunión.
context: Lenny asks what kept Jackie at Asana for eight years. Jackie explains how she grew within the company by strategically advocating for inclusion in higher-level planning meetings. When she found herself constantly asking her boss questions after his planning committee meetings, she positioned joining the meetings as a way to help him be more efficient rather than simply asking for more responsibility.
vocabulary_highlights: framing it as, help out, pretty effective way of advocating
topics: Career Development, Strategy & Planning, Communication Skills

speaker: Jackie Bavaro
speaker_expertise: Product Strategy, Product Management, Career Development
text: What I did is I wrote a document on the Local Universal Team, so I called it Local Universal Strategy. And I can't remember what I put in this document. I put it in just random... What my plan was. But once I wrote it down and shared it with people, then I started getting feedback on it. And then I could start to feel my way to what people meant to strategy.
text_ko: 제가 한 일은 로컬 유니버설 팀(Local Universal Team)에 관한 문서를 쓴 거예요. 그래서 그걸 로컬 유니버설 전략(Local Universal Strategy)이라고 이름 붙였어요. 그 문서에 정확히 뭘 적었는지 잘 기억이 안 나요. 그냥 아무렇게나, 그때 제 계획을 대충 적어놨던 것 같아요. 그런데 일단 적어서 사람들과 공유하니까 피드백이 오기 시작했고, 그러면서 사람들이 말하는 ‘전략’이 정확히 무슨 뜻인지 감을 잡을 수 있었어요.
text_zh: 我当时就写了一个关于本地全球团队的文件，我叫它"本地全球战略"。具体写了什么我都记不清了，就是随便写了一些我的想法和计划。但是一旦写下来跟大家分享了，就开始有人给反馈了。然后我就能慢慢摸索出大家对这个战略的真正想法是什么。
text_es: Lo que hice fue escribir un documento sobre el Equipo Universal Local, así que le puse Estrategia Universal Local. Y no me acuerdo qué metí en ese documento. Puse cosas medio al azar... lo que tenía planeado. Pero una vez que lo escribí y lo compartí con la gente, empecé a recibir feedback. Y ahí fue cuando empecé a tantear qué era lo que la gente realmente entendía por estrategia.
context: Lenny asks Jackie to define what strategy means in product management. Jackie explains how she initially struggled to understand strategy when she received feedback at Google that she needed to be 'more strategic' but no one could explain what that meant. She learned by writing down her strategic thinking and getting feedback, which helped her understand what others expected from strategic work.
vocabulary_highlights: feel my way to

speaker: Jackie Bavaro
speaker_expertise: Product Strategy, Product Management, Career Development
text: Three parts of strategy are your vision. This is your inspiring picture of what the future looks like. And then you've got your strategic framework. This is where you're saying, 'Here is the market we're going after. Here's what success looks like. And here are our big bets on what we think it takes to win that market.' And then the third part is the roadmap. This is where you work backwards from your vision.
text_ko: 전략(strategy)은 세 부분으로 나눌 수 있어요. 첫 번째는 비전(vision)이에요 — 미래가 어떤 모습일지 보여 주는 영감을 주는 그림이에요. 두 번째는 전략적 프레임워크(strategic framework)예요. 우리가 노리는 시장(market)이 어디인지, 성공이 어떤 모습인지, 그리고 그 시장에서 이기기 위해 우리가 크게 베팅할 것들이 무엇인지 정하는 곳이에요. 세 번째는 로드맵(roadmap)이에요. 비전에서 역산해 단계별 실행 계획으로 옮기는 부분이에요.
text_zh: 战略分三个部分。首先是愿景(vision)，就是你对未来的一个激动人心的蓝图。然后是战略框架(strategic framework)，在这里你要说清楚"我们要进军哪个市场，什么叫成功，以及我们押注什么才能拿下这个市场"。第三部分是路线图(roadmap)，就是从你的愿景倒推回来制定具体步骤。
text_es: Tres elementos conforman tu estrategia. Primero tienes tu visión. Esta es esa imagen inspiradora de cómo se ve el futuro. Luego tienes tu marco estratégico (strategic framework). Aquí es donde dices: 'Este es el mercado al que vamos. Así se ve el éxito para nosotros. Y estas son nuestras grandes apuestas sobre lo que creemos que se necesita para conquistar ese mercado.' Y el tercer elemento es la hoja de ruta (roadmap). Aquí trabajas hacia atrás desde tu visión.
context: Jackie breaks down her framework for product strategy after years of learning what strategy actually means. She identifies three essential components that any complete strategy should include: an inspiring vision of the future, a strategic framework that defines the market and approach, and a roadmap that works backward from the vision to ensure the plan is realistic and achievable.
vocabulary_highlights: big bets, work backwards

speaker: Jackson Shuttleworth
speaker_expertise: Growth Strategy, Data Analytics, User Experience
text: I'd say test everything, we've run in the last four years over 600 experiments on the streaks, so every other day. We've actually set up really good infrastructure for copy testing. We used to say continue, our standard CTA is continue, and we changed that to commit to my goal, and it was a massive win.
text_ko: 뭐든 다 테스트해 보라고 말하고 싶어요. 지난 4년 동안 스트릭스(streaks)에서 600건이 넘는 실험을 해서 거의 이틀에 한 번 꼴이었어요. 카피 테스트(copy testing)를 위한 인프라(infrastructure)도 정말 잘 마련해놨고요. 예전에는 기본 콜투액션(CTA)으로 '계속하기'를 썼는데, '내 목표에 전념하기(commit to my goal)'로 바꿨더니 효과가 정말 컸어요.
text_zh: 我觉得什么都要测试，过去四年我们在连续打卡功能上跑了600多个实验，基本上隔天就有一个。我们搭建了很不错的文案测试(copy testing)基础设施。以前我们的标准行动按钮(CTA)就是"继续"，后来改成"承诺达成我的目标"，效果特别好。
text_es: Yo diría que prueben todo, nosotros hemos hecho en los últimos cuatro años más de 600 experimentos con las rachas, prácticamente día por medio. La verdad es que montamos una infraestructura buenísima para testear copy. Antes decíamos "continuar", ese era nuestro CTA (call-to-action) estándar, y lo cambiamos a "comprometerme con mi meta", y fue un exitazo increíble.
context: Lenny asks Jackson about the key lessons and insights from Duolingo's journey of building and iterating on their streaks feature. Jackson is explaining Duolingo's philosophy of constantly testing and experimenting, sharing specific examples of how small changes like copy adjustments can have massive impact. He emphasizes the importance of testing rather than debating ideas internally, demonstrating how a simple change from 'continue' to 'commit to my goal' became a huge win for user engagement.
vocabulary_highlights: test everything, massive win, standard CTA
topics: Product Management, Growth & Marketing, Decision Making

speaker: Jackson Shuttleworth
speaker_expertise: Growth Strategy, Data Analytics, User Experience
text: And this is not just the subjective retention PM talking, I think this is our biggest feature, with the exception of the lessons. Streaks are a great engagement hack. I'm of the opinion that any team, any app out there can introduce a streak, and if you figure it out, it probably works to retain users, but at the core, you have to have an app that people want to use.
text_ko: 이건 단순히 주관적인 유지율 PM의 의견이 아니에요. 저는 이게 우리 가장 큰 특징이라고 생각해요, 수업을 제외하면요. 연속 사용(streaks)은 정말 좋은 참여 유도 방법이에요. 어떤 팀이나 앱도 연속 사용 기능을 도입할 수 있다고 생각하고, 그걸 잘 활용하면 사용자 유지에 효과적일 거예요. 하지만 가장 중요한 건 사람들이 사용하고 싶어하는 앱이 있어야 한다는 거예요.
text_zh: 这不只是我作为一个负责用户留存的产品经理(PM)的主观看法，我觉得除了课程内容本身，这就是我们最大的亮点。连续打卡(streaks)绝对是个超棒的用户粘性技巧(engagement hack)。我的观点是，任何团队、任何应用都可以加入连续打卡功能，如果你搞明白怎么做，基本上都能起到留住用户的效果。但说到底，你的应用本身得是用户真正想用的东西。
text_es: Y esto no es solo el PM de retención hablando de forma subjetiva, creo que esta es nuestra funcionalidad más importante, después de las lecciones. Las rachas son un truco genial para el engagement. Yo opino que cualquier equipo, cualquier app que esté por ahí puede meter una racha, y si le atinas, probablemente funciona para retener usuarios, pero al final del día, tienes que tener una app que la gente realmente quiera usar.
context: Lenny asks Jackson to explain the impact that the streaks feature has had on Duolingo's success and growth. Jackson is emphasizing that while streaks can be a powerful engagement mechanic for any app, they only work when layered on top of a product that users genuinely want to use. He's making the point that streaks are an 'engagement hack' - a retention tool that amplifies user engagement - but cannot substitute for core product value.
vocabulary_highlights: engagement hack, figure it out, at the core

speaker: Jackson Shuttleworth
speaker_expertise: Growth Strategy, Data Analytics, User Experience
text: We have right now over 9 million users with a year plus streak. So, 9 million of our users have used Duolingo every year, almost every day, for well over a year. Which is pretty... I don't know, I like to imagine things in terms of like, okay, well, if you put all these people in a city, or in a place, where would it be? I'm like, ah, it's like a very large city, 9 million people.
text_ko: 지금 연속 이용 기록(스트릭)이 1년 이상인 사용자가 900만 명이 넘어요. 그러니까 900만 명의 사용자가 1년 넘게 거의 매일 Duolingo를 사용해 온 셈이에요. 솔직히 저는 이런 숫자를 도시 규모로 상상하는 편이에요. 이 사람들을 한데 모아 도시로 만든다면 어느 정도일까 생각해 보면, 아, 정말 큰 도시예요 — 900만 명이나 되는.
text_zh: 我们现在有超过900万用户保持了一年以上的连续打卡记录。也就是说，有900万用户每年都在用多邻国，基本上天天都用，而且坚持了一年多。这个数字挺...怎么说呢，我喜欢把这些数字具象化一下，就是说，如果把这些人都聚到一个城市或者一个地方，那会是什么概念？我觉得就像是一个超大型城市，900万人呢。
text_es: En este momento tenemos más de 9 millones de usuarios con una racha de más de un año. O sea, 9 millones de nuestros usuarios han usado Duolingo cada año, casi todos los días, por más de un año. Lo cual es bastante... no sé, me gusta imaginarme las cosas como, bueno, si pusieras a toda esta gente en una ciudad, o en un lugar, ¿dónde sería? Y pienso, ah, sería como una ciudad muy grande, 9 millones de personas.
context: Jackson is providing concrete statistics to demonstrate the massive scale and impact of Duolingo's streaks feature. He's explaining that 9 million users have maintained streaks for over a year, meaning they've used the app almost daily for that entire period. He uses the analogy of imagining all these users as a large city to help contextualize the impressive scale of user engagement and retention that the streaks feature has achieved.
vocabulary_highlights: year plus streak, I like to imagine things in terms of

speaker: Jackson Shuttleworth
speaker_expertise: Growth Strategy, Data Analytics, User Experience
text: What Duolingo really focuses on is, how do we help users build habits around language learning? Getting user come back the next day is the biggest problem to solve. If you look at the numbers, I think pretty objectively has been our biggest growth lever for driving DAUs, and also say a lot of it's just related to how we think about growth at Duolingo.
text_ko: Duolingo가 진짜로 집중하는 건, 어떻게 하면 사람들이 언어 학습을 습관으로 만들게 도울 수 있느냐예요. 다음 날에도 사용자가 다시 돌아오게 하는 게 해결해야 할 가장 큰 문제예요. 숫자를 보면, 꽤 객관적으로 이게 일간 활성 사용자(DAUs)를 끌어올리는 우리의 가장 큰 성장 레버(growth lever)였다고 생각하고, 또 많은 부분이 Duolingo에서 성장을 바라보는 방식과 관련돼 있다고 말할 수 있어요.
text_zh: 多邻国(Duolingo)真正关注的其实是，我们怎么帮用户养成学语言的习惯？让用户第二天还会回来用，这是我们要解决的最大难题。你看数据就知道，客观来说这已经成了我们推动日活用户(DAU)增长最重要的手段，这也很大程度上反映了我们多邻国对增长的整体思路。
text_es: En lo que realmente se enfoca Duolingo es en cómo ayudamos a los usuarios a crear hábitos alrededor del aprendizaje de idiomas. Lograr que el usuario regrese al día siguiente es el mayor problema que tenemos que resolver. Si miras las cifras, creo que objetivamente ha sido nuestra palanca de crecimiento más importante para impulsar los DAUs (daily active users), y también dice mucho sobre cómo pensamos el crecimiento en Duolingo.
context: Jackson is explaining Duolingo's core philosophy and approach to user retention. He's describing how Duolingo views the challenge of language learning - that the biggest obstacle isn't the learning content itself, but getting users to return consistently to build lasting habits. He emphasizes that from a growth perspective, streaks have objectively been their most effective tool for driving daily active users, which aligns with their broader growth strategy of focusing on retention rather than just acquisition.
vocabulary_highlights: biggest growth lever, driving DAUs, pretty objectively
topics: Product Management, Growth & Marketing, Strategy & Planning

speaker: Jackson Shuttleworth
speaker_expertise: Growth Strategy, Data Analytics, User Experience
text: We actually tested, hey, what if we make it even easier to extend your streak? And so, we actually tested, hey, if you do one exercise, just one exercise in a lesson will extend your streak. What we realized when we ran this experiment is DAUs moved not one bit. And what we were doing by... And if we go back to unit of measure, we had dumbed down the unit of measure that we were basing our streak around.
text_ko: 우리는 '연속 기록(streak)을 더 쉽게 늘리면 어떨까?' 해서 실제로 실험해봤어요. 예를 들어 한 레슨에서 단 한 개의 연습만 해도 연속 기록이 연장되게 했죠. 그런데 그 실험을 해보니 일일 활성 사용자(DAU, Daily Active Users)는 전혀 변하지 않았어요. 다시 말하면 측정 단위(unit of measure)를 보면, 우리가 연속 기록을 기준으로 삼으려고 그 측정 단위를 지나치게 낮춰 버렸던 거예요.
text_zh: 我们当时就想，诶，要不我们让用户更容易维持连续学习记录？于是我们就测试了一下，如果用户只做一道题，就一道题，就能延续连续学习记录会怎么样。结果跑完这个实验我们发现，日活用户数(DAUs)一点变化都没有。我们这么做其实是...如果回到衡量标准上来说，我们把连续学习记录的衡量标准给降得太低了。
text_es: La verdad es que probamos, oye, ¿qué tal si hacemos que sea aún más fácil mantener tu racha? Entonces probamos que si haces solo un ejercicio, nada más un ejercicio en una lección, eso te mantendría la racha. Lo que nos dimos cuenta cuando corrimos este experimento es que los DAUs no se movieron ni un poquito. Y lo que estábamos haciendo... Si regresamos a la unidad de medida, habíamos simplificado demasiado la unidad de medida en la que basábamos nuestra racha.
context: Jackson is sharing a specific example of an experiment that failed, where Duolingo tested making it even easier to maintain a streak by requiring just one exercise instead of a full lesson. This was following their successful experiment of simplifying streaks from XP-based to lesson-based. He explains that this experiment taught them about the importance of having a meaningful 'unit of measure' - the core action that users need to complete. Making the requirement too easy actually captured less engaged users and provided no benefit to daily active users.
vocabulary_highlights: moved not one bit, dumbed down, unit of measure
topics: Product Management, Growth & Marketing, Decision Making

speaker: Jackson Shuttleworth
speaker_expertise: Growth Strategy, Data Analytics, User Experience
text: One of the fun ones that we did, and it's honestly as much about process as it is about the feature itself, was we have a feature called streak goal, and it is... Again, so much of this stuff seems so obvious in retrospect, but it was really novel at the time. We had this idea of like, hey, maybe we'll just goal users to hitting a certain streak length.
text_ko: 재밌게 했던 것들 중 하나는, 솔직히 기능 자체만큼이나 프로세스(process)에 관한 얘기였어요. 연속 달성 목표(streak goal)라는 기능이었는데, 그리고… 뒤돌아보면 다 뻔해 보이지만 그때는 정말 새로웠어요. ‘사용자들이 일정한 연속 기록 길이(streak length)를 달성하도록 목표를 설정하면 어떨까’ 하는 아이디어였어요.
text_zh: 我们做过一个挺有意思的功能，说实话这个功能本身和背后的流程都很重要，就是我们有个叫连击目标(streak goal)的功能。现在回头看这些东西好像都很显而易见，但在当时真的是很新颖的想法。我们就想，嘿，要不我们就让用户以达到某个连击长度为目标。
text_es: Una de las cosas divertidas que hicimos, y honestamente tiene tanto que ver con el proceso como con la funcionalidad en sí, fue que tenemos una función que se llama meta de racha (streak goal), y es... otra vez, muchas de estas cosas parecen súper obvias cuando las ves hacia atrás, pero en su momento fue realmente innovador. Teníamos esta idea de, oye, qué tal si simplemente motivamos a los usuarios a llegar a cierta longitud de racha.
context: Jackson is describing the development of Duolingo's 'streak goal' feature, which allows users to commit to reaching specific streak milestones. He's emphasizing how innovations often seem obvious in hindsight but were novel when first conceived. This feature emerged from focusing on the critical 0-7 day user experience, where they discovered that once users reach a 7-day streak, loss aversion kicks in and retention dramatically improves. The streak goal feature helps guide users toward that crucial milestone.
vocabulary_highlights: in retrospect, really novel at the time, goal users to hitting

speaker: Jag Duggal
text: We rarely scale a project, a product we've launched, until we know the Sean Ellis score and we know that it's hit a threshold that we find really compelling. The Sean Ellis score is a really simple methodology used by lots and lots of companies that a gentleman named Sean Ellis popularized well over a decade ago.
text_ko: 저희는 보통 프로젝트나 출시된 제품을 바로 확장(scale)하지 않아요. 먼저 션 엘리스 스코어(Sean Ellis score)를 확인해서 그 점수가 저희가 정말 매력적이라고 느끼는 기준(threshold)을 넘을 때까지 기다려요. 션 엘리스 스코어는 션 엘리스(Sean Ellis)라는 분이 10년이 훨씬 넘게 전에 널리 알린, 많은 회사들이 쓰는 아주 단순한 방법론이에요.
text_zh: 我们很少会去扩大一个项目或者已经上线的产品规模，除非我们知道肖恩·埃利斯得分(Sean Ellis score)，而且确认它达到了我们认为很有说服力的那个门槛。肖恩·埃利斯得分(Sean Ellis score)其实是个很简单的方法论，现在很多很多公司都在用，是一个叫肖恩·埃利斯的人在十多年前推广开的。
text_es: Casi nunca escalamos un proyecto o un producto que hemos lanzado hasta que conocemos el puntaje de Sean Ellis y sabemos que ha alcanzado un umbral que nos parece realmente atractivo. El puntaje de Sean Ellis (Sean Ellis score) es una metodología súper sencilla que usan muchísimas empresas y que un señor llamado Sean Ellis popularizó hace más de una década.
context: Lenny asks about how Nubank measures whether customers truly love their products before scaling them. Jag explains that they use the Sean Ellis score methodology, which asks customers how disappointed they would be if the product went away. At Nubank, they require at least 50% of customers to say they would be 'very disappointed' before scaling a product, which is higher than the typical 40% threshold due to Brazilian customers being more polite and optimistic.
vocabulary_highlights: hit a threshold, really compelling, popularized well over a decade ago

speaker: Jag Duggal
text: Good enough, isn't good enough. Is it great enough? Because that's the bar, particularly for some of our ten-pole products, but we try to apply it largely across the board. A lot of companies spend a ton of money on marketing. Their VC budgets, VC funding basically goes to Google and Facebook.
text_ko: '그냥 괜찮다' 수준으론 안 돼요. 충분히 훌륭한가요? 그게 기준이에요. 특히 몇몇 주력 제품에는 더 그렇고, 가능한 한 전반에 걸쳐 적용하려고 해요. 많은 회사가 마케팅에 엄청난 돈을 써요. 그들의 벤처캐피털(VC) 자금은 사실상 구글과 페이스북으로 가요.
text_zh: 差不多好，那可不够。得问问是不是真的够棒？这就是我们的标准，特别是对那些十柱产品(ten-pole products)，但我们基本上全线都这么要求。很多公司在营销上砸大钱，风投资金(VC funding)基本上都流到谷歌和脸书那儿去了。
text_es: "Suficientemente bueno" no es suficiente. ¿Es lo suficientemente genial? Porque ese es el estándar, especialmente para algunos de nuestros productos estrella (ten-pole products), pero tratamos de aplicarlo en general a todo. Muchas empresas se gastan una fortuna en marketing. Sus presupuestos de capital de riesgo, básicamente la financiación de VC se va directo a Google y Facebook.
context: Lenny is asking about Nubank's approach to building products people love fanatically. Jag shares a phrase from their lead designer about raising the bar beyond just 'good enough' to 'great enough.' He explains this philosophy helps them avoid spending heavily on marketing since truly great products generate word-of-mouth growth instead of requiring massive advertising budgets.
vocabulary_highlights: ten-pole products, largely across the board, spend a ton of money

speaker: Jag Duggal
text: Don't ask a researcher to come up with a plan to go do the research to then summarize it, to then bring it to you, which has so many degrees of distance built in. You pick up the phone, call 10 of them and nine times out of 10, by the time you've made your fifth call, you could predict what's customer six, seven, eight, nine and 10 are going to tell you.
text_ko: 연구자한테 '조사 계획 짜고, 연구해서 요약해 가져와라'고 시키지 마세요. 그건 중간 단계가 너무 많아서 거리감이 생겨요. 그냥 전화를 들어 열 명 정도에게 직접 물어보세요. 열 번 중 아홉 번은 다섯 번째 통화까지 해보면 나머지 사람들이 뭐라고 할지 다 예측할 수 있어요.
text_zh: 别让研究员先做个研究计划，然后去调研，再总结汇报给你，这中间隔了好几层。你直接拿起电话打给10个客户，十有八九，打到第五个的时候，你就能猜到后面几个客户会跟你说什么了。
text_es: No le pidas a un investigador que te arme un plan para hacer la investigación, después resumirla y luego traértela—eso tiene demasiados filtros de por medio. Mejor agarra el teléfono, llama directamente a 10 clientes, y te aseguro que en 9 de cada 10 casos, para cuando hagas la quinta llamada, ya vas a poder predecir exactamente qué te van a decir los clientes seis, siete, ocho, nueve y diez.
context: Lenny asks about how product managers can get closer to customer feedback. Jag explains Nubank's approach of having product managers directly call customers rather than going through multiple layers of research intermediaries. He advocates for this direct approach because it eliminates the distance between the product builder and customer voice, and patterns emerge quickly after just a few conversations.
vocabulary_highlights: degrees of distance built in, nine times out of 10, could predict

speaker: Jag Duggal
text: We are not going to take a small problem and scale it because if we do that, we end up with a big mess. Something isn't working at small scale, no problem, especially if we have a strong hypothesis and a lot of ways of getting good customer feedback. We iterate, we iterate, we get it right and then once we get it right, scaling if you do it right in many cases takes care of itself.
text_ko: 작은 문제를 그대로 확장(scale)하진 않을 거예요. 그렇게 하면 결국 큰 난장판이 되거든요. 작은 규모에서 잘 안 되면 괜찮아요. 특히 명확한 가설(hypothesis)이 있고 고객 피드백(customer feedback)을 받을 방법이 많다면요. 계속 반복(iterate)해서 개선해요. 제대로 맞출 때까지요. 그리고 일단 제대로 맞추면, 확장(scale)은 많은 경우 저절로 해결돼요.
text_zh: 我们不会拿一个小问题直接放大，因为那样做最后就是一团糟。如果在小规模时就有问题，其实没关系，特别是当我们有很强的假设和很多渠道能拿到好的客户反馈。我们就不断迭代(iterate)，不断迭代，直到做对为止。一旦做对了，扩张这件事如果方法得当，很多时候就是水到渠成的事。
text_es: No vamos a agarrar un problema chiquito y escalarlo porque si hacemos eso, terminamos con un desastre enorme. Si algo no está funcionando a pequeña escala, no hay bronca, sobre todo si tenemos una hipótesis sólida y muchas formas de conseguir buen feedback de los clientes. Iteramos, iteramos, lo hacemos bien y después, una vez que lo tenemos bien, el escalamiento, si lo haces correctamente, en muchos casos se cuida solo.
context: Lenny is discussing the pressures product managers face to scale products quickly. Jag explains Nubank's disciplined approach of not scaling products until they have achieved product-market fit at a small scale. He emphasizes that it's better to solve problems when they're small rather than create bigger messes by scaling prematurely, and that proper scaling often happens naturally once the product is truly working.
vocabulary_highlights: end up with a big mess, takes care of itself

speaker: Jag Duggal
text: We may not be right, but at least we are clear. Even if your strategy isn't right, and it will never be exactly right because no plan ever is, you will have a clearer read on if you are going off course because you have a very clear idea of what was supposed to be happening.
text_ko: 우리가 꼭 옳지 않을 수도 있지만, 적어도 상황은 분명해요. 전략이 완전히 맞을 수는 없어요—어떤 계획도 완벽하진 않으니까요. 하지만 무엇이 일어나야 하는지 분명히 알고 있으면, 우리가 방향을 벗어나고 있는지 훨씬 더 빨리, 더 정확하게 파악할 수 있어요.
text_zh: 我们可能不一定对，但至少我们心里有数。就算你的策略不完全正确——其实也不可能完全正确，因为没有哪个计划是完美的——但你至少能清楚地知道自己是不是走偏了，因为你对原本应该怎么走心里很清楚。
text_es: Puede que no tengamos la razón, pero al menos tenemos las cosas claras. Aunque tu estrategia no sea la correcta, y nunca va a ser perfecta porque ningún plan lo es, vas a poder darte cuenta mucho mejor si te estás desviando del camino porque tienes muy claro qué se suponía que tenía que pasar.
context: Lenny asks Jag about his approach to strategy development. Jag quotes Kevin Systrom from Instagram's early days to illustrate the importance of strategic clarity. He argues that having a clear strategy, even if imperfect, allows teams to quickly identify when they're going off course because they have concrete expectations about what should be happening.
vocabulary_highlights: clearer read on, going off course, supposed to be happening

speaker: Jag Duggal
text: We're not trying to be incrementally better. We are trying to be fundamentally different. We're in the business of being fundamentally different, not incrementally better. Only fundamentally different, gets customers to tell their friends. Incrementally better and there are certain features where you're in the incrementally better business, but we're searching for those anchors that are going to be fundamentally different all the time.
text_ko: 우리는 단지 점진적 개선(incrementally better)을 하려는 게 아니에요. 우리는 근본적 차이(fundamentally different)를 만들려고 해요. 우리의 사업은 점진적 개선이 아니라 근본적 차이를 만드는 일이에요. 고객이 친구에게 소개하게 만드는 건 오직 근본적으로 다른 것뿐이에요. 물론 어떤 기능들은 점진적 개선의 영역에 있어서 그걸 하는 경우도 있지만, 우리는 항상 근본적으로 다를 핵심 요소(anchors)를 찾고 있어요.
text_zh: 我们不是想做得稍微好一点点，我们是要做得完全不一样。我们要做的就是根本性的差异化，而不是小修小补的改进。只有做到根本性的不同，客户才会主动给朋友推荐。如果只是稍微改进一下，当然某些功能确实需要渐进式优化，但我们一直在寻找那些能让我们彻底与众不同的核心支撑点。
text_es: No estamos buscando ser un poquito mejores que la competencia. Estamos tratando de ser radicalmente diferentes. Nuestro negocio es ser radicalmente diferentes, no mejorar por pedacitos. Solo cuando eres radicalmente diferente es que los clientes les van a contar a sus amigos. Con mejoras incrementales, sí, hay ciertas funcionalidades donde puedes apostar a esas mejoras graduales, pero nosotros estamos buscando constantemente esos puntos clave que nos van a hacer radicalmente diferentes.
context: Lenny is asking about Nubank's philosophy and approach to product development. Jag explains their core principle that appears on company mugs - they focus on being fundamentally different rather than incrementally better. He clarifies that while some features may be incremental improvements, they constantly search for anchor products and experiences that are fundamentally different because only those drive word-of-mouth growth.
vocabulary_highlights: incrementally better, fundamentally different, searching for those anchors

speaker: John Zeratsky
speaker_expertise: Product Design, Venture Capital, Leadership Development
text: One phenomenon we've seen when teams are building things really quickly with AI is that the more AI-generated or assisted they are, the more generic they tend to turn out. Put yourself in a situation where you can slow down and do some hard thinking, some deep thinking about what's actually going to make your product unique. Going fast can actually slow you down in the long run.
text_ko: 인공지능(AI)을 써서 아주 빠르게 무언가를 만드는 팀들을 보면 한 가지 공통된 현상이 있어요. AI가 많이 생성하거나 보조할수록 결과물이 더 평범해지는 경향이 있더라고요. 일부러 속도를 늦추고 제품이 진짜로 무엇으로 차별화될지 깊게 고민할 수 있는 상황을 만들어 보세요. 단기적으로 빨리 가는 것이 좋아 보여도, 장기적으로는 오히려 발목을 잡아서 더 느리게 만들 수 있어요.
text_zh: 我们发现一个现象，就是团队用AI快速开发产品的时候，AI生成或辅助得越多，做出来的东西就越千篇一律。你得让自己慢下来，好好想想，深入思考一下到底什么能让你的产品与众不同。一味求快，长远来看反而会拖慢你的步伐。
text_es: Un fenómeno que hemos notado cuando los equipos están desarrollando cosas súper rápido con IA es que entre más generada o asistida por IA sea, más genérica tiende a salir. Ponte en una situación donde puedas bajar el ritmo y hacer un pensamiento profundo, una reflexión seria sobre qué es lo que realmente va a hacer único tu producto. Ir muy rápido en realidad te puede hacer más lento a largo plazo.
context: Lenny asks why teams shouldn't just build something quickly and launch it to learn, rather than spending time on strategic planning. John explains a counterintuitive problem with AI-assisted development: while AI tools allow teams to build faster than ever, they often produce generic solutions because LLMs are trained on existing data. He argues that without taking time to think deeply about differentiation upfront, teams may waste time building something that looks polished but fails to stand out in the market.
vocabulary_highlights: AI-generated or assisted, generic they tend to turn out, hard thinking, deep thinking, in the long run
topics: Product Management, Strategy & Planning, Decision Making

speaker: Jake Knapp
speaker_expertise: Product Design, Venture Capital, Product Management
text: We would have a conversation with founders, you're saying like, 'Gosh, I'm almost embarrassed to ask this question, but who exactly is your target customer?' And three co-founders have three different answers.
text_ko: 창업자들과 얘기할 때면, "정말 이런 질문 드리기가 좀 민망한데요, 정확히 누가 당신들의 타깃 고객(target customer)이에요?"라고 물어보곤 해요. 그런데 공동창업자들(co-founders) 세 명이 저마다 다른 대답을 해요.
text_zh: 我们跟创始人聊天的时候，会说："不好意思啊，这个问题可能有点尴尬，但你们的目标客户到底是谁？"结果三个联合创始人给出三个完全不同的答案。
text_es: Teníamos conversaciones with fundadores donde les decíamos algo como: "Oye, casi me da pena preguntar esto, pero ¿quién es exactamente tu cliente objetivo?" Y resulta que los tres cofundadores te dan tres respuestas completamente diferentes.
context: Jake introduces a common problem they've observed when working with startup founders. Despite seeming like basic questions, fundamental aspects of a business strategy are often unclear or misaligned among team members. This example illustrates why the Foundation Sprint process is necessary - even successful, intelligent founders frequently lack alignment on core business questions that seem obvious but are actually quite complex to define precisely.
vocabulary_highlights: almost embarrassed to ask, who exactly is, three different answers
topics: Starting a Company, Leadership & Management, Strategy & Planning

speaker: John Zeratsky
speaker_expertise: Product Design, Venture Capital, Leadership Development
text: After these hundreds of teams that we've worked with, we've seen that there's one failure mode, which is they don't know what that set of basics are. Then there's this other failure mode where they never test it.
text_ko: 우리가 함께 일해온 수백 개의 팀을 보면, 한 가지 실패 유형(failure mode)이 있어요 — 팀들이 어떤 기본이 필요한지 모른다는 거예요. 또 다른 실패 유형은 그 기본을 아예 검증하지 않는다는 거예요.
text_zh: 我们跟几百个团队合作下来，发现有两个常见的坑：一个是他们根本不知道什么是基础要素，另一个是知道了但从来不去验证测试。
text_es: Después de trabajar con cientos de equipos, hemos visto que hay un tipo de fallo, que es cuando no saben cuáles son esos fundamentos básicos. Y luego está este otro tipo de fallo donde nunca lo ponen a prueba.
context: John identifies two common patterns of failure they've observed across hundreds of startup teams they've worked with at Google Ventures and Character Capital. The first failure mode occurs when teams haven't clearly defined fundamental aspects like target customer and competitive differentiation. The second happens when teams think they know these basics but never validate their assumptions with real customers, leading to building products that don't achieve product-market fit.
vocabulary_highlights: failure mode, set of basics, never test it
topics: Starting a Company, Product Management, Strategy & Planning

speaker: Jake Knapp
speaker_expertise: Product Design, Venture Capital, Product Management
text: The very beginning of your project, we recommend this kind of crazy idea that you clear your calendar. So the core team come together for 10 hours roughly and go through a sequence of activities so that we can make all of the key decisions together.
text_ko: 프로젝트 초반에는 일정을 전부 비워두는 다소 과감한 방법을 추천해요. 핵심 팀(core team)이 한자리에 모여 대략 10시간 정도 집중해서 일련의 활동(sequence of activities)을 진행하면서 모든 주요 의사결정을 함께 내리는 방식이에요.
text_zh: 在项目刚开始的时候，我们建议你们来个疯狂的想法——把日程全部清空。让核心团队聚在一起大概10个小时，一起做一系列的活动，这样我们就能把所有关键决策都敲定了。
text_es: Al mero inicio de tu proyecto, te recomendamos esta idea medio loca de que liberes tu agenda. Así el equipo principal se junta como unas 10 horas y pasa por una serie de actividades para que podamos tomar todas las decisiones clave juntos.
context: Lenny asks Jake to explain how the Foundation Sprint process works. Jake describes the unconventional but essential first step: dedicating focused, uninterrupted time for strategic alignment. The Foundation Sprint requires the core leadership team (co-founders, heads of product, engineering, design, and marketing) to commit 10 hours over two days to work through structured activities that establish the fundamental strategy and hypothesis for their startup or product.
vocabulary_highlights: kind of crazy idea, clear your calendar, sequence of activities, key decisions together
