topics: Strategy & Planning, Leadership & Management, Decision Making

speaker: Jake Knapp
speaker_expertise: Product Design, Venture Capital, Product Management
text: We're going to use the advantages we have. We're going to use our insight, we're going to use our motivation, we're going to use our special capabilities. These are things, again, people are aware of these things, they're in tune to it, but we want to get super, super specific.
text_ko: 우리가 가진 장점들을 활용할 거예요. 통찰력도 활용하고, 동기도 활용하고, 우리만의 특별한 역량도 활용할 거예요. 이런 건 다들 알고 공감하는 부분이지만, 저희는 여기서 훨씬 더 구체적으로 들어가려고 해요. 정말 정말 구체적으로요.
text_zh: 我们要把自己的优势都用上。我们的洞察力要用上，我们的动力要用上，还有我们的特殊能力也要用上。这些东西大家其实都知道，也都有感觉，但是我们要做得非常非常具体。
text_es: Vamos a aprovechar las ventajas que tenemos. Vamos a usar nuestra visión estratégica, vamos a usar nuestra motivación, vamos a usar nuestras capacidades especiales. Estas son cosas que, bueno, la gente ya las conoce, ya están al tanto, pero queremos ser súper, súper específicos.
context: Jake explains the differentiation phase of the Foundation Sprint, which focuses on identifying what sets a startup apart from competitors. Rather than competing on generic factors like price or speed, successful startups need to leverage their unique advantages - special insights about the market, personal motivation for solving the problem, or distinctive capabilities the team possesses. The key is making these advantages explicit and specific rather than keeping them as vague assumptions.
vocabulary_highlights: in tune to it, super, super specific, special capabilities
topics: Strategy & Planning, Starting a Company, Product Management

speaker: John Zeratsky
speaker_expertise: Product Design, Venture Capital, Leadership Development
text: While you're outsourcing that prototyping work, you don't outsource the thinking. You don't kind of skip over the part where you think about, 'Well, what is the actual copy on the website? How do I actually describe what the product is, how it's differentiated?'
text_ko: 그 프로토타이핑(prototyping) 작업을 아웃소싱(outsourcing)으로 맡기더라도, 아이디어나 전략 같은 생각하는 부분까지는 아웃소싱할 수는 없어요. '웹사이트에 실제로 들어갈 카피는 뭘로 할까? 제품을 어떻게 설명하고, 어떤 점에서 차별화되는지 어떻게 표현할까?' 같은 고민은 건너뛰면 안 돼요.
text_zh: 虽然你可以把原型制作(prototyping)外包出去，但是思考这一块儿你可不能外包。你不能跳过那些需要动脑子的环节，比如说"网站上到底写什么文案？我怎么描述这个产品？它的差异化在哪儿？"这些问题你都得自己想清楚。
text_es: Aunque subcontratas el trabajo de prototipos, no subcontratas el pensamiento. No puedes saltarte la parte donde te pones a pensar: "Bueno, ¿cuál va a ser el copy real del sitio web? ¿Cómo describo realmente qué es el producto y cómo se diferencia?"
context: John discusses how AI tools are changing the prototyping process in design sprints. While AI can rapidly generate realistic-looking prototypes and marketing materials, he warns against letting AI handle the strategic thinking behind those outputs. Teams must still do the hard work of defining their unique value proposition, target messaging, and differentiation strategy before using AI to execute and build prototypes based on that strategic foundation.
vocabulary_highlights: outsourcing that prototyping work, outsource the thinking, skip over the part, how it's differentiated
topics: Product Management, Strategy & Planning, Decision Making

speaker: Jake Knapp
speaker_expertise: Product Design, Venture Capital, Product Management
text: To set the answer up, I'll give you a super brief history of Make Time. And for over a decade, John and I have been, in quotes, designing time as part of our work with startups, helping them find or expand product market fit. So, we developed a design sprint at Google Ventures, which the Sprint book is about.
text_ko: 답변을 준비하기 위해, Make Time의 간단한 역사를 말씀드릴게요. 존과 저는 10년 넘게 스타트업과 함께 일하면서, '시간을 디자인하는' 작업을 해왔어요. 그 과정에서 제품 시장 적합성(product market fit)을 찾거나 확장하는 데 도움을 줬죠. 그래서 구글 벤처스에서 디자인 스프린트(design sprint)를 개발하게 되었고, 그에 관한 책이 바로 '스프린트(Sprint)'예요.
text_zh: 先简单说说《腾出时间》这本书的背景。十多年来，我和约翰一直在做"时间设计"这件事，帮助初创公司找到或扩大产品市场匹配度(product market fit)。所以我们在谷歌风投开发了设计冲刺(design sprint)方法，《冲刺》那本书讲的就是这个。
text_es: Para contextualizarte, te voy a dar un resumen súper breve de la historia de Make Time. Durante más de una década, John y yo hemos estado, entre comillas, diseñando el tiempo como parte de nuestro trabajo con startups, ayudándoles a encontrar o expandir el ajuste producto-mercado (product market fit). Así que desarrollamos un sprint de diseño (design sprint) en Google Ventures, que es de lo que trata el libro Sprint.
context: Lenny asks Jake what most people get wrong when they're trying to become more productive. Jake begins by explaining the background of their book Make Time and how it emerged from their work with startups. He describes how they've been 'designing time' for over a decade through their work helping startups find product-market fit, which led to developing design sprints at Google Ventures.
vocabulary_highlights: in quotes, find or expand product market fit

speaker: Jake Knapp
speaker_expertise: Product Design, Venture Capital, Product Management
text: So, even though we are not productivity gurus, this hasn't been like this thing we were doing forever, it's not our full-time job, but we thought we want to share this framework. So, Make Time, the book and the blog that proceeded it was just kind this side project to share what we learned. And yeah, it seems like it is resonated with a bunch of people.
text_ko: 저희는 생산성 전문가(productivity gurus)는 아니고, 오래전부터 해오던 일도 아니고 전업으로 하는 일도 아니었어요. 다만 이 프레임워크(framework)를 다른 사람들과 나누고 싶었어요. 그래서 Make Time이라는 책과 그보다 먼저 시작한 블로그는 우리가 배운 걸 공유하려는 사이드 프로젝트(side project)였고요. 그런데 의외로 많은 분들에게 공감을 얻은 것 같아요.
text_zh: 所以，虽然我们不是什么生产力大师，这也不是我们一直在做的事情，也不是我们的全职工作，但我们觉得想把这套方法分享出来。所以，《腾出时间》这本书，还有之前的博客，就是我们的一个副业项目，想分享一下我们学到的东西。看起来确实引起了很多人的共鸣。
text_es: Entonces, aunque no somos gurús de la productividad, esto no es algo que hayamos estado haciendo toda la vida, no es nuestro trabajo de tiempo completo, pero pensamos que queríamos compartir este marco de trabajo (framework). Así que Make Time, el libro y el blog que lo precedió, fue como este proyecto paralelo para compartir lo que aprendimos. Y sí, parece que ha conectado con un montón de gente.
context: Jake continues explaining the origin story of their Make Time book. He emphasizes that they aren't traditional productivity experts - this wasn't their main career focus, but rather emerged as a side project to share practical lessons they discovered while working with startups on design sprints and applying those insights to their personal productivity.
vocabulary_highlights: productivity gurus, side project, resonated with a bunch of people

speaker: John Zeratsky
speaker_expertise: Product Design, Venture Capital, Leadership Development
text: Our perspective is basically that those are the defaults. Just like our software that we use, apps that we use have defaults, those are the defaults of life, of the companies that we work in, the culture that we live in. And so, the solution is actually to change those defaults and to really flip this way of thinking on its head.
text_ko: 저희 관점은 그런 것들이 바로 기본값(defaults)이라는 거예요. 우리가 쓰는 소프트웨어(software)나 앱(apps)에 기본값이 있듯이, 삶이나 우리가 다니는 회사, 우리가 속한 문화에도 그런 기본값이 있다는 뜻이에요. 그래서 해결책은 그 기본값을 바꾸고, 이런 사고방식을 완전히 뒤집는 거예요.
text_zh: 我们的观点其实很简单，那些就是默认设置。就像我们用的软件、APP都有默认设置一样，这些就是生活的默认设置，包括我们工作的公司、我们身处的文化环境。所以解决方案其实就是要改变这些默认设置，把这种思维方式彻底颠覆过来。
text_es: Nuestra perspectiva es básicamente que esas son las configuraciones por defecto. Igual que el software que usamos, las aplicaciones que manejamos tienen sus ajustes predeterminados, esos son los defaults de la vida, de las empresas donde trabajamos, de la cultura en la que vivimos. Entonces, la solución en realidad es cambiar esos defaults y darle la vuelta completa a esta forma de pensar.
context: Lenny asks about what people get wrong with productivity, and John explains their core philosophy. He argues that most productivity advice focuses on being more efficient at existing tasks (emails, meetings), but their approach is about changing the fundamental defaults of how we structure our time, similar to how software has default settings that can be customized.
vocabulary_highlights: flip this way of thinking on its head

speaker: Jake Knapp
speaker_expertise: Product Design, Venture Capital, Product Management
text: The idea of the busy bandwagon is just this expectation that everybody's busy. And in the United States, there's kind of this thing that I think if you travel abroad and talk to people for a while, then you come back, you'll notice, which is like if you ask someone, 'Hey, how's it going? What are you up to?' And they'll be like, 'Oh man, I'm busy.'
text_ko: 바쁜 밴드왜건(busy bandwagon)이라는 생각은 결국 모두가 바쁘다고 기대하는 거예요. 미국에는 그런 경향이 있는데요, 해외에 좀 다녀와서 사람들과 얘기해 보면 돌아오면 더 확실히 느껴져요. 예를 들어 '요즘 어때? 뭐 해?'라고 물어보면 다들 '아, 나 바빠요'라고들 해요.
text_zh: 忙碌跟风(busy bandwagon)这个概念就是说，大家都觉得每个人都应该很忙。在美国，有这么一种现象，我觉得如果你出国待一段时间，跟当地人聊聊，然后回来你就会发现——就是当你问别人"嘿，最近怎么样？在忙什么呢？"他们就会说"哎呀，忙死了。"
text_es: La idea de esta moda de estar ocupado es simplemente esa expectativa de que todo el mundo está súper ocupado. Y en Estados Unidos, hay como una cosa que creo que si viajas al extranjero y hablas con la gente un rato, y luego regresas, te das cuenta, que es como si le preguntas a alguien: "Oye, ¿cómo te va? ¿Qué tal todo?" Y te van a decir: "Ay, hermano, estoy ocupadísimo."
context: Lenny asks about the concepts of 'busy bandwagon' and 'infinity pools' that prevent people from making time for important things. Jake explains the busy bandwagon as a cultural expectation in the US where being busy is the default response and almost a badge of honor, creating internal pressure to always appear busy and reactive to others' demands.
vocabulary_highlights: busy bandwagon

speaker: John Zeratsky
speaker_expertise: Product Design, Venture Capital, Leadership Development
text: And so, when you put these two things together, the busy bandwagon and the infinity pool, you kind of have this, it's like a flywheel, but bad. You feel like you really need to be busy, you really need to be on top of everything. And then, you've got this whole collection of apps and services and products there that are ready to pounce on that.
text_ko: 그래서 이 두 가지, 바쁜 밴드왜건(busy bandwagon)과 인피니티 풀(infinity pool)을 합치면, 말하자면 플라이휠(flywheel) 같은 효과가 나는데 좋은 플라이휠이 아니라 안 좋은 쪽이에요. 정말 바쁘지 않으면 안 될 것 같고, 모든 걸 다 챙겨야 한다는 압박을 느끼게 돼요. 그러면 그걸 노리듯 수많은 앱·서비스·제품이 바로 달려들 준비를 하고 있어요.
text_zh: 所以说，当你把这两个东西放在一起——忙碌的从众心理(busy bandwagon)和无限信息池(infinity pool)，就形成了一种恶性循环，就像飞轮(flywheel)一样，但是是坏的那种。你会觉得自己必须得忙起来，什么事都得跟上节奏。然后呢，就有一大堆应用、服务和产品在那儿等着，随时准备"收割"你。
text_es: Entonces, cuando juntas estas dos cosas, el rollo de estar siempre ocupado y esa piscina infinita de contenido, tienes como una especie de rueda que se retroalimenta, pero para mal. Sientes que de verdad necesitas estar ocupado todo el tiempo, que tienes que estar al día con todo. Y ahí tienes un montón de apps, servicios y productos listos para aprovecharse de eso.
context: John is explaining how the busy bandwagon (cultural pressure to be busy) combines with infinity pools (endlessly refreshing content like social media and email) to create a destructive cycle. He describes how these two forces work together - the internal pressure to stay busy meets apps designed to capture attention, creating what he calls 'a flywheel, but bad.'
vocabulary_highlights: flywheel, but bad, ready to pounce on that

speaker: Jake Knapp
speaker_expertise: Product Design, Venture Capital, Product Management
text: At any given point in time, I probably give myself a B to B-, and sometimes it's a C and sometimes it's a D, and sometimes it's an A, and I'm really plugging away, but it's totally an ongoing challenge. So, I'm not going to sit here and say, yeah, just follow me with a drone for 48 hours and you'll think that's exactly how you should do things.
text_ko: 지금 이 순간 제 자신을 평가해보면 보통 B에서 B- 정도라고 생각해요. 가끔은 C, 때로는 D일 때도 있고, 또 어떤 땐 A를 준다고 느낄 때도 있어요. 정말 열심히 하고 있지만 계속되는 도전이에요. 그래서 제가 여기서 '48시간 동안 드론(drone)으로 저만 따라다니면 이게 바로 일하는 방식의 정답이라고 생각하게 될 거예요'라고 말하진 않겠어요.
text_zh: 不管什么时候，我给自己打分的话，大概就是B到B-吧，有时候是C，有时候是D，偶尔能拿个A，我一直在努力，但这真的是个持续的挑战。所以我不会坐在这儿跟你说，嘿，你跟着我48小时，然后就觉得我做的就是标准答案。
text_es: En cualquier momento dado, probablemente me pondría un B o B-, y a veces es un C y a veces un D, y de vez en cuando un A, y sigo dale que dale, pero es un desafío constante. Así que no voy a sentarme aquí y decir, sí, sígueme con un dron por 48 horas y vas a pensar que así es exactamente como debes hacer las cosas.
context: Lenny asks Jake and John about their own productivity and how well they follow their Make Time framework. Jake gives an honest assessment of his own performance, rating himself between B- and D most days. He emphasizes that productivity is an ongoing challenge and he doesn't want to present himself as having it all figured out perfectly.
vocabulary_highlights: plugging away, follow me with a drone

speaker: Jake Knapp
speaker_expertise: Product Design, Venture Capital, Product Management
text: The notion what the highlight is, start your day out and you imagine it's the end of the day, you're looking back on the day. If someone asked you, 'What was the highlight of your day,' what would you say? What do you want to say at the end of today was the highlight of today?
text_ko: 하루를 시작할 때 마치 그날이 이미 끝나서 되돌아보고 있는 것처럼 상상해 보세요. 누군가가 "오늘의 하이라이트가 뭐였어요?"라고 물으면 뭐라고 답하고 싶으세요? 오늘 하루가 끝날 때 "오늘의 하이라이트는 이거였어요"라고 말하고 싶게 만드는 건 뭘까요?
text_zh: 这个概念就是说，一天开始的时候，你想象一下今天已经结束了，你在回顾这一天。如果有人问你"今天最棒的事情是什么"，你会怎么回答？今天结束的时候，你希望能说什么是今天的亮点？
text_es: La idea es esta: empiezas tu día imaginándote que ya es el final del día y estás viendo hacia atrás. Si alguien te preguntara "¿Qué fue lo mejor de tu día?", ¿qué responderías? ¿Qué quieres poder decir al final de hoy que fue lo mejor del día?
context: Jake is explaining the concept of a 'highlight' - the central component of their Make Time framework. This is about choosing one main thing you want to accomplish each day by imagining what you'd want to tell someone was the best part of your day. It's the anchor that helps you structure your time around what truly matters to you.
vocabulary_highlights: looking back on the day

speaker: John Zeratsky
speaker_expertise: Product Design, Venture Capital, Leadership Development
text: So, most days, the first half of the day before lunch is my focus time, and I protect that very, very intensely, and then use that time to work on whatever my highlight is.
text_ko: 보통 점심 전 오전이 제 집중 시간이어서 그 시간을 정말 철저히 지켜요. 그 시간엔 그날의 하이라이트(highlight)에만 집중해요.
text_zh: 所以呢，大部分时候，上午到午饭前这段时间是我的专注时间，我会非常非常严格地保护这个时间段，然后用这个时间来处理我当天的重点工作。
text_es: Entonces, la mayoría de los días, toda la mañana hasta el almuerzo es mi tiempo de concentración, y lo cuido muchísimo, y uso ese tiempo para trabajar en lo que sea mi prioridad del día.
context: John is describing his personal implementation of the Make Time framework as a venture capitalist. He explains how he structures his calendar to prioritize focused work time for his daily highlight, despite the naturally chaotic and meeting-heavy environment of VC work. This shows how to apply the highlight concept in a demanding professional context.
vocabulary_highlights: protect that very, very intensely

speaker: Jake Knapp
speaker_expertise: Product Design, Venture Capital, Product Management
text: This thing, I think we basically are steered toward becoming reaction machines and this notion of, 'I'm going to have an empty inbox. I'm going to do every task. I'm going to be a fast responder, I'm going to be in every meeting. I'm going to do that because I want to help other people, and that's the way it works.'
text_ko: 제 생각에는 결국 우리를 반응만 하는 기계(reaction machines)로 몰아가는 것 같아요. '인박스를 비워야 해(inbox zero). 모든 업무를 다 해내고, 답장은 빨리 하고, 모든 회의에 참석해야 해. 남을 도우려는 마음에서 그런 거고, 그게 정상적인 방식이라는 생각' 말이에요.
text_zh: 我觉得这事儿吧，我们基本上都被推着变成了反应机器，就是那种想法——"我要把邮箱清空，每个任务都要做，要秒回消息，每个会都要参加。我这么做是因为想帮助别人，觉得就应该这样。"
text_es: Mira, creo que básicamente nos están convirtiendo en máquinas de reaccionar, con esa mentalidad de "voy a tener el correo vacío, voy a hacer todas las tareas, voy a responder súper rápido, voy a estar en todas las reuniones. Lo voy a hacer porque quiero ayudar a los demás, y así es como funciona esto."
context: Jake is explaining why people struggle with productivity and fall into reactive patterns. He describes how the desire to be helpful and responsive leads people to become 'reaction machines' - constantly responding to others' demands rather than focusing on their own important work. This reactive mode prevents people from doing meaningful, proactive work.
vocabulary_highlights: reaction machines, fast responder

speaker: Janna Bastow
text: Honestly, it wasn't so much that we set out to build a community, it was that we got together with some product people with the idea that we didn't know what we were doing. And so we figured if we got together with some other product people and started chatting it through, we'd all learn together. And so it was just the sense of sharing and collaborating and learning from each other and just keeping it as grassroots as possible as it grew.
text_ko: 솔직히 처음부터 커뮤니티를 만들려고 한 건 아니었어요. 그냥 우리도 뭘 잘 모른다는 생각으로 프로덕트 사람들(product people) 몇 명이 모였던 거예요. 그래서 다른 프로덕트 사람들과 만나서 얘기해보면 같이 배울 수 있겠다 싶었고요. 결국 서로 나누고 협력하고 서로에게서 배우는 그런 분위기였고, 커져도 최대한 풀뿌리(grassroots) 방식으로 유지하려고 했어요.
text_zh: 说实话，我们一开始并不是想着要建个社群什么的，而是几个做产品的人聚在一起，觉得自己也不太懂，摸着石头过河嘛。所以我们想，不如找些同行一起聊聊，大家互相学习。就是这种分享、合作、互相学习的想法，而且尽量保持那种草根的感觉，让它自然发展。
text_es: La verdad es que no fue tanto que nos propusiéramos crear una comunidad desde el principio, sino que nos juntamos con gente de producto con la idea de que no teníamos ni idea de lo que estábamos haciendo. Entonces dijimos, "si nos juntamos con otros colegas de producto y empezamos a conversar sobre esto, todos vamos a aprender juntos." Y así fue, simplemente con esa mentalidad de compartir y colaborar y aprender unos de otros, manteniéndolo lo más orgánico posible mientras iba creciendo.
context: Lenny asks Janna about what has been most important in building and maintaining the quality of the Mind the Product community, which is the world's largest community of product managers. Janna explains that they didn't initially set out to build a community but rather came together with other product people because they felt uncertain about their work. The key insight is that successful communities often grow organically from genuine shared learning needs rather than being artificially constructed.
vocabulary_highlights: set out to, chatted it through, grassroots as possible

speaker: Janna Bastow
text: When running a conference, it's one of the most expensive and unleanest things you can possibly do. It's really difficult as a product person to pull that off, because it pulls at your heart. You want to do something that's lean iterative, but you can't. If something screws up with the lunch order, for example, you can't fix it.
text_ko: 컨퍼런스(conference)를 운영하는 건 할 수 있는 일 중에서 가장 비용이 많이 들고 린(lean)하지 않은 것 중 하나예요. 프로덕트 담당자(product person)로서는 그걸 해내기가 정말 어려워요. 마음이 끌리거든요. 린(lean)하고 반복적인(iterative) 방식으로 하고 싶어도 그럴 수가 없어요. 예를 들어 점심 주문이 꼬이면 그걸 바로 고칠 수가 없어요.
text_zh: 办会议真的是最烧钱、最不精益(lean)的事情了。作为做产品的人，这种事特别难搞，因为心里很纠结。你明明想做精益迭代(lean iterative)的事情，但是没办法。比如说午餐订餐出了问题，你根本没法补救。
text_es: Cuando organizas una conferencia, es una de las cosas más caras y menos ágiles que puedes hacer. Es súper difícil como product manager porque va contra todo lo que crees. Quieres hacer algo lean (ágil) e iterativo, pero no puedes. Si se jode el pedido del almuerzo, por ejemplo, ya no lo puedes arreglar.
context: Lenny asks Janna about mistakes they made while building their community. Janna explains the challenges of running conferences, particularly how they conflict with typical product management principles. She describes conferences as 'unlean' because unlike product development where you can iterate quickly, conference problems must be solved in real-time without the ability to iterate until the following year.
vocabulary_highlights: unleanest, pulls at your heart, screws up

speaker: Janna Bastow
text: One of the things that I have been super lucky in my career is that by being part of Mind the Product I've gotten to watch every last Mind the Product speaker, top end speakers. I've been able to see every ProductTank London speaker, and a lot of the other ProductTank speakers around the world. Been able to see what people react to, what works, what doesn't work.
text_ko: 제 경력에서 진짜 운이 좋았던 것 중 하나는 Mind the Product(마인드 더 프로덕트)에 함께하면서 모든 연사들—특히 톱급 연사들까지—직접 볼 수 있었던 거예요. ProductTank London(프로덕트탱크 런던)의 연사들도 전부 봤고, 전 세계 다른 ProductTank(프로덕트탱크)들의 발표도 많이 지켜봤어요. 덕분에 사람들이 무엇에 반응하는지, 무엇이 효과가 있고 무엇이 잘 안 먹히는지를 직접 알 수 있었죠.
text_zh: 我职业生涯中特别幸运的一点就是，通过参与Mind the Product这个组织，我有机会观摩了每一位Mind the Product的演讲嘉宾，都是顶级的那种。我还能看到每一位ProductTank伦敦站的演讲者，以及全世界其他ProductTank活动的很多演讲者。能够亲眼看到观众对什么有反应，什么管用，什么不管用。
text_es: Una de las cosas en las que he tenido muchísima suerte en mi carrera es que al ser parte de Mind the Product he podido ver a todos, pero todos los speakers de Mind the Product, speakers de primer nivel. He podido ver a todos los speakers de ProductTank London, y a muchos de los speakers de ProductTank de todo el mundo. He podido ver a qué reacciona la gente, qué funciona, qué no funciona.
context: Lenny asks Janna about what has helped her become a better speaker and storyteller, noting that communication skills are crucial for product leaders. Janna explains that her unique position with Mind the Product gave her extensive exposure to high-quality speakers. This allowed her to develop pattern recognition for effective presentations by observing audience reactions and understanding what techniques work versus what fails.
vocabulary_highlights: top end speakers, react to

speaker: Janna Bastow
text: One of the things that I've stopped doing is I used to sit down with a PowerPoint and start writing my deck in PowerPoint or Slides, now. What I now do is I start with my story points. I start with my narratives. I try to figure out what I'm actually trying to say, and then I fit it into the deck.
text_ko: 예전에는 파워포인트(PowerPoint)나 슬라이드(Slides)를 켜고 바로 덱(deck)을 만들곤 했어요. 이제는 먼저 스토리 포인트(story points)와 내러티브(narratives)를 정리해서, 제가 실제로 뭘 말하려는지 먼저 정한 다음에 그 내용을 덱에 맞춰 넣어요.
text_zh: 我现在改变了一个做法，以前我会直接打开PPT开始做幻灯片，现在不这样了。我现在是先把故事线想清楚，先把要讲的内容梳理好，先搞明白我到底想表达什么，然后再去做PPT。
text_es: Una de las cosas que ya no hago es sentarme directamente con PowerPoint y empezar a armar mi presentación ahí mismo, o en Slides ahora. Lo que hago ahora es empezar con mis puntos clave de la historia. Empiezo con mis narrativas. Trato de entender qué es lo que realmente quiero comunicar, y después lo adapto a la presentación.
context: Lenny asks Janna about lessons from her speaking coach that she continues to apply to new presentations. Janna shares a key insight about presentation preparation methodology. She explains that she used to get trapped in 'presentation mode' by starting with slides, but now focuses on crafting the narrative first and then building slides to support that story, which creates more compelling and coherent presentations.
vocabulary_highlights: story points, fit it into the deck

speaker: Janna Bastow
text: So the whole beef with the timeline roadmap is just taking apart the concept of the timeline. It doesn't mean we live in la la land. It doesn't mean that we don't believe in having dates on the roadmap, if there is a date that we have to work towards. It just means not penalizing ourselves by having a date on everything on the roadmap.
text_ko: 타임라인 로드맵(timeline roadmap)에 대한 논점은 결국 타임라인이라는 개념 자체를 다시 뜯어보자는 거예요. 그렇다고 우리가 현실을 모르는 환상 속에 산다는 뜻은 아니고요. 또 로드맵에 날짜를 넣는 것을 반대한다는 의미도 아니에요 — 만약 우리가 맞춰야 할 날짜가 있다면 그 날짜를 두고 일하는 건 당연히 해요. 다만 로드맵의 모든 항목마다 굳이 날짜를 달아 스스로를 불필요하게 압박하지 말자는 뜻이에요.
text_zh: 所以时间线路线图(timeline roadmap)的问题其实就是要重新审视一下时间线这个概念。这不是说我们要活在理想世界里，也不是说如果真的有必须完成的日期，我们就不在路线图上标日期。只是说不要给路线图上的每件事都硬性规定日期，这样搞得自己很被动。
text_es: Mira, el problema que tenemos con los cronogramas de la hoja de ruta (timeline roadmap) es simplemente desmontar el concepto del cronograma. No significa que vivamos en las nubes. No significa que no creamos en poner fechas en la hoja de ruta, si hay una fecha hacia la cual tenemos que trabajar. Solo significa no castigarnos poniendo fecha a cada cosa en la hoja de ruta.
context: Lenny asks Janna to explain her strong feelings against Gantt-based roadmapping. Janna clarifies her position on timeline-based roadmaps, explaining that she's not against all dates but rather against forcing artificial deadlines on every item. Her 'now, next, later' framework allows for dates when genuinely necessary (like regulatory deadlines) while avoiding the problems that arise when everything must have a timeline commitment.
vocabulary_highlights: whole beef with, live in la la land, penalizing ourselves

speaker: Janna Bastow
text: So the value isn't the prototype, the value is in the prototyping process. The value isn't in your roadmap, the value is in the roadmapping process. What you're actually doing is laying out your assumptions of the problems that you're solving. So you're saying, 'I think we have this problem, then this problem. What do you think?'
text_ko: 그러니까 가치가 프로토타입(prototype) 자체에 있는 게 아니라 프로토타이핑 과정(prototyping process)에 있는 거예요. 로드맵(roadmap) 자체에 가치가 있는 게 아니라 로드맵 작성 과정(roadmapping process)에 가치가 있어요. 실제로는 해결하려는 문제들에 대한 가정(assumptions)을 정리하는 거고, 그래서 ‘이런 문제가 있는 것 같고, 다음에는 이런 문제가 있을 것 같은데, 어떻게 생각하세요?’라고 묻는 거예요.
text_zh: 所以真正有价值的不是原型本身，而是做原型的这个过程。有价值的也不是你的路线图，而是制定路线图的过程。你其实在做的事情就是把你对要解决的问题的假设都摊开来说。就是告诉别人，"我觉得我们有这个问题，还有那个问题，你怎么看？"
text_es: Entonces el valor no está en el prototipo, sino en el proceso de hacer prototipos. El valor no está en tu hoja de ruta (roadmap), sino en el proceso de planificarla. Lo que realmente estás haciendo es poner sobre la mesa tus suposiciones sobre los problemas que estás resolviendo. Es decir, estás diciendo: "Yo creo que tenemos este problema, y después este otro. ¿Tú qué opinas?"
context: Janna is explaining her concept of roadmaps as 'prototypes for your strategy' rather than fixed plans. She draws an analogy to how product teams prototype features - you create mockups to test assumptions with stakeholders, then iterate based on feedback. Similarly, roadmaps should be used to test strategic assumptions about what problems to solve and in what order, allowing for feedback and iteration rather than serving as unchangeable commitments.
vocabulary_highlights: laying out your assumptions

speaker: Janna Bastow
text: You're not asking for any more leeway than your sales team. You're saying that you want a quarter million dollars worth of investment, and you're going to spend it on your team who's going to run experiments, right? It's going to be trying this change on the interface or that tweak to the pricing or that change to the positioning or whatever you're going to do.
text_ko: 영업팀(sales team)한테 주는 것만큼 재량을 더 달라는 건 아니에요. 당신은 25만 달러(quarter million dollars)짜리 투자를 요청하는 거고, 그걸 실험을 돌릴 팀에 쓸 거라고 말하는 거죠. 인터페이스(interface)를 이렇게 바꿔보거나, 가격 책정(pricing)을 약간 조정해보거나, 포지셔닝(positioning)을 바꿔보는 등 하려는 실험들을 해보는 거예요.
text_zh: 你要的灵活度其实跟你们销售团队要的没什么区别。你是想要25万美金的投资，然后把这笔钱花在团队身上让他们去做各种试验，对吧？就是在界面上试试这个改动，或者调调定价策略，或者换换产品定位(positioning)什么的。
text_es: No estás pidiendo más flexibilidad que tu equipo de ventas. Lo que dices es que quieres una inversión de un cuarto de millón de dólares, y la vas a invertir en tu equipo que va a hacer experimentos, ¿verdad? Van a probar este cambio en la interfaz o ese ajuste en los precios o ese cambio en el posicionamiento o lo que sea que vayan a hacer.
context: Lenny asks Janna for the most powerful arguments to convince skeptics that less rigid deadline-driven roadmapping could work at their company. Janna uses an analogy comparing product development to sales processes. She argues that sales teams aren't expected to predict exactly which deals will close when, but rather are given budgets to run experiments (sales calls) knowing some will succeed and some will fail. Product teams should be given similar leeway to run experiments rather than being held to artificial deadline commitments.
vocabulary_highlights: leeway, run experiments, tweak to the pricing

speaker: Jason Droege
text: Like with any of these major tech revolutions, headlines tell one story and then on the ground, laying broadband means you need to dig up every single road in America to lay it. Someone's got to dig up the road or someone's got to run the undersea cable.
text_ko: 이런 주요 기술 혁명들처럼 헤드라인은 한쪽 이야기만 전해주는데, 실제로는 광대역(broadband)을 깔려면 미국의 거의 모든 도로를 일일이 파헤쳐야 해요. 누군가는 도로를 파야 하고, 또 누군가는 해저 케이블(undersea cable)을 깔아야 하죠.
text_zh: 就像之前那些重大的科技革命一样，媒体报道说得天花乱坠，但真正干起来的时候，要铺宽带就得把美国的每条路都挖一遍。总得有人去挖路，有人去铺海底光缆，这些脏活累活还是得有人干。
text_es: Como pasa con cualquier revolución tecnológica importante, los titulares cuentan una historia, pero la realidad sobre el terreno es otra: tender banda ancha significa que tienes que levantar cada carretera de Estados Unidos para instalarla. Alguien tiene que hacer el trabajo sucio de excavar las calles o tender los cables submarinos.
context: Lenny asks Jason about the gap between AI hype and reality, noting that people think AI gets trained on all human knowledge when actually experts are sitting around teaching AI specific things it doesn't know. Jason explains that while AI models seem magical, there's always operational work behind major technological advances - just like how laying broadband infrastructure required physical cable installation across the country.
vocabulary_highlights: on the ground, laying broadband, dig up every single road, run the undersea cable

speaker: Jason Droege
text: The general trend right now is going from models knowing things to models doing things. The next question becomes, what can it do for me? How does the agent make decisions for you?
text_ko: 지금 전반적인 추세는 모델(models)이 단순히 아는 것에서 실제로 하는 것으로 넘어가고 있어요. 다음으로 제기되는 질문은 그게 저한테 무엇을 해줄 수 있느냐는 점이고, 에이전트(agent)가 저를 위해 어떻게 의사결정을 내려주느냐가 관건이에요.
text_zh: 现在的大趋势就是从模型"知道什么"转向模型"能做什么"。接下来的问题就是，它到底能为我做些什么？这个智能体(agent)怎么帮我做决策？
text_es: La tendencia general en este momento es pasar de modelos que saben cosas a modelos que hacen cosas. La siguiente pregunta que surge es: ¿qué puede hacer por mí? ¿Cómo toma decisiones el agente por ti?
context: Lenny asks Jason what people don't understand about where AI models are heading in the next 2-3 years, given Jason's unique perspective working with labs on unreleased capabilities. Jason explains the current shift in AI development - models have become quite robust at knowledge tasks, but the next frontier is getting them to take actions and navigate real systems like Salesforce or healthcare platforms.

speaker: Jason Droege
text: 18 months ago, you would get a short story and it would say, 'Is this short story better than this short story?' And now you're at a point where one task is building an entire website by one of the world's best web developers, or it is explaining some very nuanced topic on cancer to a model. These tasks now take hours of time and they require PhDs and professionals.
text_ko: 18개월 전만 해도 단편소설 하나를 넣으면 결과가 '이 단편이 저 단편보다 낫나요?' 정도였어요. 그런데 지금은 상황이 완전히 달라졌어요. 어떤 작업은 세계 최고 수준의 웹 개발자(web developer) 중 한 사람이 통째로 웹사이트를 만드는 수준이고, 또 어떤 작업은 모델(model)에게 암(cancer)의 아주 미묘한 주제를 설명해야 하는 일이에요. 이런 작업들은 이제 몇 시간씩 걸리고 박사(PhDs)나 전문가들이 필요해요.
text_zh: 18个月前，你拿到一个小故事，系统会问你"这个故事好还是那个故事好？"现在呢？任务变成了让世界顶级的网站开发者去搭建整个网站，或者让模型去解释癌症方面特别复杂的专业问题。这些任务现在得花好几个小时，而且必须要博士或者专业人士才能搞定。
text_es: Hace año y medio, te daban un cuento corto y te preguntaban '¿Este cuento es mejor que este otro?' Y ahora estamos en un punto donde una tarea es construir un sitio web completo como lo haría uno de los mejores desarrolladores web del mundo, o explicarle a un modelo algún tema súper complejo sobre cáncer. Estas tareas ahora toman horas y requieren gente con doctorados y profesionales especializados.
context: Lenny discusses how the data labeling industry has shifted from low-cost generalist workers to requiring experts like doctors and engineers. Jason explains how dramatically the complexity of training tasks has evolved at Scale - what used to be simple preference rankings between short stories has become sophisticated work requiring deep expertise, with tasks now taking hours instead of minutes and requiring advanced degrees.
vocabulary_highlights: very nuanced topic

speaker: Jason Droege
text: From an entrepreneurship standpoint, it truly is about what insight do I have? Why am I so lucky to have this insight? Why in a world of a million entrepreneurs who are thinking, who are smart, who are trying everything, why am I in the position where I likely have an insight that others do not?
text_ko: 창업자 관점(entrepreneurship standpoint)에서 보면, 결국 제가 어떤 통찰(insight)을 갖고 있느냐가 중요해요. 그런데 왜 제가 그런 통찰을 가질 만큼 운이 좋은 걸까요? 생각하고 똑똑하고 무엇이든 시도하는 수백만 명의 창업자들이 있는 세상에서, 왜 하필 제가 다른 사람들에겐 없는 통찰을 가질 가능성이 높은 위치에 있는 걸까요?
text_zh: 从创业的角度来说，关键就是我到底有什么独到的见解？我凭什么这么幸运能有这种洞察力？在这个世界上有成千上万的创业者，他们都在思考，都很聪明，什么都在尝试，那我凭什么能处在这样一个位置，很可能拥有别人没有的洞察？
text_es: Desde el punto de vista del emprendimiento, realmente se trata de qué perspectiva única tengo yo. ¿Por qué tengo la suerte de tener esta visión? ¿Por qué en un mundo lleno de millones de emprendedores que están pensando, que son inteligentes, que lo están intentando todo, por qué estoy yo en la posición donde probablemente tengo una perspectiva que otros no tienen?
context: Lenny asks Jason about setting a high bar for new businesses and independent thinking. Jason explains his philosophy on entrepreneurship - with so many smart people trying to start companies, founders need to honestly assess what unique insight they possess that others don't have, rather than just pursuing any business opportunity they discover through customer research.
vocabulary_highlights: why am I so lucky, in a world of a million entrepreneurs

speaker: Jason Droege
text: These things take 6 to 12 months to get them truly robust enough where an important process can be automated. If you actually do that, the impact is like, whoa, I never would've figured that out myself, and I'm one of the most educated doctors in the world as an example. But the time to get there is just longer than what people are selling.
text_ko: 이런 건 중요한 프로세스를 자동화(automated)할 수 있을 만큼 진짜 안정적(robust)이 되려면 6개월에서 12개월은 걸려요. 실제로 그렇게 하면 효과가 ‘와, 나 혼자서는 절대 못 알아냈을 거예요’ 싶을 정도예요 — 예를 들어 저처럼 세계에서 손꼽히게 교육받은 의사 중 한 명조차요. 그런데 그 수준에 도달하는 데 걸리는 시간은 사람들이 홍보하는 것보다 훨씬 더 길어요.
text_zh: 这些东西要真正做到足够稳定，能够自动化重要流程，得花6到12个月的时间。如果你真的做到了，那效果简直让人刮目相看，就像"哇，这个我自己根本想不出来"，比如我作为世界上受教育程度最高的医生之一都会这么想。但是达到这种程度所需要的时间，比那些销售人员吹的要长得多。
text_es: Estas cosas tardan de 6 a 12 meses en volverse realmente sólidas como para poder automatizar un proceso importante. Si logras hacerlo bien, el impacto es impresionante - jamás me hubiera imaginado eso por mi cuenta, y mira que soy uno de los médicos más preparados del mundo, por ejemplo. Pero el tiempo que lleva llegar ahí es mucho más largo de lo que te están vendiendo.
context: Lenny asks about AI not delivering on enterprise promises, citing studies showing failed pilots and lack of adoption. Jason explains that while there's hype around AI, successful implementations require months of work including legal approval, policy changes, and achieving high accuracy standards. He contrasts the reality of building robust AI systems with the quick demos people see in promotional videos.
vocabulary_highlights: truly robust enough, whoa, I never would've figured that out myself

speaker: Jason Droege
text: The end is never the end. You got to survive before you thrive, which is your brain tells you, and along these entrepreneurial journeys, I think this is most applicable. If you go on this journey for five years, you are mentally harder than 99.9% of the population.
text_ko: 끝은 결코 끝이 아니에요. 번창하기 전에 살아남아야 해요 — 우리 뇌가 그렇게 말하거든요. 특히 이런 창업 여정(entrepreneurial journeys)에서는 더 그렇다고 생각해요. 이 길을 5년 동안 걸으면 정신적으로 인구의 99.9%보다 훨씬 강해져요.
text_zh: 结束从来都不是真正的结束。你得先活下来，才能发展壮大，这是你的大脑告诉你的道理。在创业这条路上，我觉得这个道理最管用了。如果你在创业路上坚持了五年，你的心理承受能力就比99.9%的人都要强。
text_es: El final nunca es el final. Tienes que sobrevivir antes de prosperar, eso es lo que te dice tu cerebro, y en estos caminos empresariales, creo que esto es lo más aplicable. Si te mantienes en este viaje por cinco años, mentalmente eres más fuerte que el 99.9% de la población.
context: Lenny asks Jason about his favorite life motto. Jason shares 'the end is never the end' and explains how entrepreneurial journeys involve constant mental challenges and self-doubt that feel insurmountable, but remininding yourself that you'll wake up tomorrow and find solutions helps you push through what seems like impossible situations.
vocabulary_highlights: survive before you thrive, mentally harder than 99.9% of the population, Chinese water torture

speaker: Jason Feifer
text: It's ridiculous. I would say that by the time we are done recording this podcast, I'll have, I don't know. I mean, it could be anywhere from 30 to 50 pitches in my inbox. It comes all day. Now, to be clear, most of that is garbage in the real garbagey sense, right. It's a lot of completely unrelevant press releases that were sent to me and a bazillion other people.
text_ko: 정말 어이가 없어요. 이 팟캐스트 녹음이 끝날 때쯤이면, 글쎄요… 제 받은 편지함(inbox)에 아마 30에서 50개 정도의 피치(pitches)가 들어와 있을 거예요. 하루 종일 계속 들어와요. 분명히 말하면, 그 중 대부분은 진짜 쓰레기예요, 말 그대로요. 완전히 관련 없는 보도자료(press releases)들이 저한테랑 수많은 다른 사람들에게 한꺼번에 발송된 거예요.
text_zh: 这太夸张了。我跟你说，等我们录完这期播客，我的邮箱里估计又得有，我也说不准，反正30到50个推销邮件(pitch)是跑不了的。这玩意儿一整天都在往里蹦。不过说实话，这里面大部分都是垃圾，真正的垃圾那种，对吧。基本上都是些跟我八竿子打不着的新闻稿，群发给我和其他一大堆人的。
text_es: Es una locura. Te diría que para cuando terminemos de grabar este podcast, voy a tener, no sé... Pueden ser entre 30 y 50 propuestas en mi bandeja de entrada. Me llegan todo el día. Ahora, para que quede claro, la mayoría de eso es pura basura, basura de la buena, ¿eh? Son un montón de comunicados de prensa que no tienen nada que ver conmigo y que me los mandaron a mí y a otros miles de personas.
context: Lenny asks Jason about the volume of pitches he receives from startup founders and PR people trying to get coverage. Jason is explaining the overwhelming amount of press pitches he receives daily as editor-in-chief of Entrepreneur Magazine. He emphasizes that most pitches are mass-distributed, irrelevant press releases rather than targeted, thoughtful outreach.
vocabulary_highlights: real garbagey sense, bazillion other people, completely unrelevant

speaker: Jason Feifer
text: And that means that you could end up... I write this newsletter, right. I have... Entrepreneur Magazine is the thing that people obviously would pitch, but then I have this newsletter where I don't interview anybody. There's no opportunity to be featured in my newsletter, and I still get pitches to the newsletter because somebody saw it and dropped it in some spreadsheet, and it just... now I get it. And I think that's a real disservice to entrepreneurs who are paying for people to do that, and I really hate that.
text_ko: 그 말은 결국… 제가 뉴스레터(newsletter)를 하나 쓰고 있다는 건데요. Entrepreneur Magazine 같은 곳은 당연히 피치(pitch)할 대상이 되겠지만, 제 뉴스레터는 사람 인터뷰를 하지 않아요. 제 뉴스레터에 소개될 기회 자체가 없는데도 누군가가 보고 스프레드시트(spreadsheet)에 넣어둔 탓에 계속 저한테까지 피치가 들어와요. 이제는 왜 그런지 알겠어요. 그런데 그게 PR이나 홍보업체에 비용을 지불하는 창업자들에게는 정말 불이익이라고 생각하고, 저는 그거 진짜 싫어요.
text_zh: 这就意味着你可能会遇到这种情况...我写这个newsletter(邮件通讯)，对吧。我有...《创业家》杂志是大家明显会想要推销的地方，但是我还有这个newsletter，我在里面不采访任何人。根本没有机会在我的newsletter里露脸，但我还是会收到各种推销邮件，就因为有人看到了，然后随手扔进某个Excel表格里，现在就...我明白了。我觉得这对那些花钱请人做推广的创业者来说真的是很坑，我特别讨厌这种做法。
text_es: Y eso significa que puedes terminar... yo escribo este newsletter, ¿no? Tengo... la revista Entrepreneur es obviamente lo que la gente querría que les publique, pero también tengo este newsletter donde no entrevisto a nadie. No hay manera de que te destaquen en mi newsletter, y aún así me siguen llegando propuestas para el newsletter porque alguien lo vio y lo metió en alguna hoja de cálculo, y ya... ahora me llega de todo. Y creo que eso es hacerles muy mal servicio a los emprendedores que están pagando por eso, y la verdad es que lo odio.
context: Jason explains how automated PR systems work poorly for entrepreneurs. He describes how PR agencies often add publications to spreadsheets without understanding what they actually cover. Jason uses his own newsletter as an example - it doesn't feature interviews or stories about companies, yet he still receives irrelevant pitches because someone added it to a database without researching its format or purpose.
vocabulary_highlights: dropped it in some spreadsheet, real disservice

speaker: Jason Feifer
text: Think about press the same way that you think about raising money, which is to say you do it when you know what the money is for, and you should do it when you know what the press is for. A lot of people reach out to me at such an early stage that if we wrote about them, it wouldn't get them anything. They're not at a stage where they could use that press in any meaningful way, and so there's really no purpose in chasing it now.
text_ko: 언론(press)을 다루는 건 자금 조달(raising money)을 생각하는 방식과 똑같이 생각하세요. 돈을 모을 때 '이 돈이 뭘 위해 쓰일지' 분명할 때만 하는 것처럼, 언론을 활용할 때도 '언론이 어떤 도움이 될지' 알 때 해야 해요. 많은 분들이 너무 이른 단계에 저한테 연락을 주시는데, 그때 기사화가 된다 해도 실질적으로 얻는 게 별로 없어요. 지금은 언론 보도를 의미 있게 활용할 단계가 아니라서 굳이 쫓을 필요가 없어요.
text_zh: 做媒体报道就像融资一样，你得先想清楚钱拿来干什么用，同样的，你也得先想清楚媒体报道要达到什么目的。很多人太早就找到我，要是我们这时候报道他们，其实对他们一点好处都没有。他们现在这个阶段，根本用不上媒体曝光，所以现在去追求这些报道完全没意义。
text_es: Piensa en los medios de la misma manera que piensas en conseguir financiamiento: lo haces cuando sabes para qué vas a usar ese dinero, y con la prensa debería ser igual, hazlo cuando sepas para qué te va a servir esa cobertura. Un montón de gente me contacta en etapas súper tempranas, y si escribiéramos sobre ellos, no les serviría para nada. No están en un punto donde puedan aprovechar esa exposición de manera significativa, así que realmente no tiene sentido perseguirla ahorita.
context: Lenny asks Jason when it's worth investing time in getting press coverage. Jason draws a parallel between seeking press and fundraising, emphasizing that both should be pursued strategically when you have a clear purpose. He explains that many entrepreneurs seek press too early in their company's development, when coverage wouldn't actually benefit their business goals or stage.
vocabulary_highlights: chasing it, meaningful way, no purpose in

speaker: Jason Feifer
text: But I get a lot of emails. It's funny because people are... like entrepreneurs, in particular, they're just so vulnerable, and it's kind of a wonderful way sometimes. And sometimes people will just email me, and they'll just say, "You know, I've worked really hard, and I just feel like I deserve this." I respect that, and I relate to it in some ways with my own trying to get attention for my own work. But, "I deserve this" that's not a good tactical decision for your business that doesn't do anything for you.
text_ko: 근데 저한테 이메일이 정말 많이 와요. 웃긴 건 사람들이, 특히 창업가들(entrepreneurs)은 되게 취약할 때가 많고, 그게 가끔은 오히려 참 좋은 방식이 되기도 해요. 가끔은 그냥 이메일로 "저 정말 열심히 일했으니까 이건 제가 받을 자격이 있어요"라고만 쓰기도 해요. 그런 마음은 존중하고, 저도 제 일을 알리려고 애썼던 경험이 있어서 어느 정도 공감해요. 하지만 "내가 받을 자격이 있어" 같은 생각은 사업에 있어서 좋은 전술적 결정(tactical decision)이 아니고, 실질적으로 별로 도움이 되지 않아요.
text_zh: 不过我收到很多邮件。有意思的是，创业者们特别容易流露真心，有时候这样挺好的。有时候有人会给我发邮件，就直接说："你知道吗，我真的很努力，我觉得我应该得到这个机会。"我能理解这种想法，我自己为了给作品争取关注度的时候也有过类似感受。但是，"我应该得到"这种想法对你的生意来说不是什么好策略，对你没什么帮助。
text_es: Pero recibo un montón de emails. Es curioso porque la gente... como los emprendedores, en particular, son muy vulnerables, y a veces es algo hermoso. Y a veces la gente me escribe y me dice, "Sabes qué, he trabajado muy duro, y siento que me lo merezco." Lo respeto, y en cierta forma me identifico con eso por mis propios intentos de llamar la atención sobre mi trabajo. Pero eso de "me lo merezco"... esa no es una buena decisión táctica para tu negocio, eso no te sirve de nada.
context: Jason continues explaining when it makes sense to pursue press coverage. He describes the emotional vulnerability of entrepreneurs who sometimes reach out saying they 'deserve' press coverage after working hard. While Jason empathizes with this feeling, he emphasizes that deserving coverage isn't a strategic business reason that will actually help achieve meaningful goals.
vocabulary_highlights: so vulnerable, I deserve this, tactical decision

speaker: Jason Feifer
text: So that means that 99.5% of the people who would read a story about this guy have no ability to go get his hotdogs, which means that that was wasted effort. So fine. Was it that hard to come up and talk to me at the conference? No. But scale that out. How many emails is he sending that are like that? How much energy is he putting into chasing things that ultimately don't have good direct value to him?
text_ko: 그러니까 이 얘기를 읽는 사람들 중 99.5%는 그 사람 핫도그를 사러 갈 수도 없는 사람들이란 뜻이에요. 그건 결국 노력 낭비였어요. 그럼 컨퍼런스에서 와서 나한테 그냥 말을 걸어보는 게 그렇게 어려웠을까요? 아니에요. 그런데 그걸 확장해 보면 (scale that out), 그런 식의 이메일을 그가 몇 통이나 보내고 있을까요? 결국 그에게 직접적인 가치(direct value)가 별로 없는 것들을 쫓느라 얼마나 많은 에너지를 쓰고 있는 걸까요?
text_zh: 这就是说，99.5%看到这个人故事的读者根本没法去买他的热狗，也就是说这些努力都白费了。好吧，在会议上过来跟我聊聊有那么难吗？没有。但你想想规模化的问题，他发了多少封这样的邮件？他把多少精力都浪费在追求那些对他来说根本没有直接价值的事情上？
text_es: Eso significa que el 99.5% de la gente que leería una historia sobre este tipo no puede ni siquiera ir a comprar sus hot dogs, o sea que fue esfuerzo perdido. Bueno, vale. ¿Era tan difícil acercarse a hablar conmigo en la conferencia? No. Pero ahora multiplica eso. ¿Cuántos emails estará mandando que son así? ¿Cuánta energía estará metiendo en perseguir cosas que al final no le van a dar buen retorno directo?
context: Jason tells the story of a hot dog food truck owner in Washington DC who wanted coverage in Entrepreneur Magazine. Jason explains why this would be ineffective - Entrepreneur has a national/international audience, but the hot dog vendor can only serve local customers. Jason uses this example to illustrate how entrepreneurs often target the wrong publications that don't reach their actual customer base.
vocabulary_highlights: scale that out, chasing things, direct value

speaker: Jason Feifer
text: They don't care about you. They don't care about you. They care about their reader or their listener or their viewer. That's who they care about. That's who they're serving, and if you can be of use to them in sharing the kinds of information that they are looking to serve their audience, then you can get what you want. But you can't treat them like a service provider because they're not.
text_ko: 그들은 당신에게 관심 없어요. 정말 관심 없어요. 그들이 신경 쓰는 건 독자나 청취자, 시청자예요. 바로 그 사람들이 그들이 돌보는 대상이고, 그들을 위해 일하는 사람들입니다. 만약 당신이 그들이 자기 청중에게 전달하려는 종류의 정보를 공유하는 데 도움이 될 수 있다면, 당신도 원하는 걸 얻을 수 있어요. 하지만 그들을 서비스 제공자(service provider)처럼 대하면 안 돼요. 그건 그들이 아니니까요.
text_zh: 他们根本不在乎你。真的，他们就是不在乎你。他们在乎的是他们的读者、听众或者观众。这些人才是他们真正关心的，他们就是为这些人服务的。如果你能帮到他们，提供他们想要分享给受众的那种信息，那你就能得到你想要的。但是你不能把他们当成服务商来对待，因为他们压根儿就不是。
text_es: No les importas tú. No les importas para nada. Les importa su lector, su oyente o su audiencia. Esa es la gente que les importa. A esos es a quienes están sirviendo, y si tú les puedes ser útil compartiendo el tipo de información que ellos buscan para servir a su audiencia, entonces puedes conseguir lo que quieres. Pero no los puedes tratar como si fueran un proveedor de servicios porque no lo son.
context: Jason explains a fundamental misunderstanding entrepreneurs have about media. Many people approach journalists and editors as if they're service providers whose job is to give coverage. Jason clarifies that media professionals' primary loyalty is to their audience, not to the people pitching them stories. He emphasizes that successful pitches must demonstrate value to the publication's readers rather than just promoting the entrepreneur's business.
vocabulary_highlights: be of use to them, service provider

speaker: Jason Feifer
text: So when people would pitch what we'd really be looking for are, are there insights into... in what this person is doing that other people could read and say, "Aha, that helps me understand where this industry is going or that industry, or it helps me think about how I can shape my own company to match current trends," that kind of stuff.
text_ko: 그래서 사람들이 피치를 할 때 우리가 실제로 보려는 건, 그 사람이 하는 일에서 다른 사람들이 읽고 “아, 이걸 보니까 이 업계가 어디로 가는지 알겠네, 아니면 우리 회사도 지금 흐름에 맞게 어떻게 바꿔야 할지 생각해 보게 되네”라고 말할 수 있는 인사이트(insights)가 있는지 보는 거예요.
text_zh: 所以当有人来提案的时候，我们真正想要的是——这个人做的事情能不能给别人一些启发，让别人看了会恍然大悟："哦，原来如此！这让我明白了这个行业的发展方向，或者那个行业的走势，或者让我知道怎么调整自己公司的策略来跟上当下的趋势。"就是这种东西。
text_es: Entonces cuando la gente nos venía con propuestas, lo que realmente buscábamos era si había insights... en lo que esta persona estaba haciendo que otros pudieran leer y decir "¡Ajá! Esto me ayuda a entender hacia dónde va esta industria o aquella, o me ayuda a pensar en cómo puedo adaptar mi propia empresa para seguir las tendencias actuales", ese tipo de cosas.
context: Jason explains the editorial mission differences between publications, using his experience at Fast Company as an example. When he worked at Fast Company under editor-in-chief Bob Safian, the magazine focused on where business was heading and evolution of industries. Jason describes what made stories appealing to Fast Company - they needed to provide insights that would help readers understand industry trends and adapt their own companies accordingly.
vocabulary_highlights: match current trends, that kind of stuff

speaker: Jason Fried
text: We run a very different kind of business. We are focused on efficiency, we're not focused on growth. They're focused on growth. So typically, when you have a lot of people, you think you can do more things at once, and you probably can. You do more things at once, and have different offerings to different people, and different tiers, and salespeople, and all the things that build up an organization.
text_ko: 우리는 좀 다른 방식의 사업을 해요. 저희는 효율성(efficiency)에 초점을 맞추고 있고, 성장(growth)에만 집중하진 않아요. 반대로 그쪽은 성장에 집중하죠. 보통 사람 수가 많아지면 한꺼번에 더 많은 일을 할 수 있다고 생각하게 되고, 아마 어느 정도는 그럴 수 있어요. 동시에 여러 일을 하고, 고객마다 다른 상품(offering)을 내놓거나 티어(tier)를 나누고, 영업 담당자(salespeople)를 두는 등 조직을 키우는 데 필요한 여러 요소들이 생겨나요.
text_zh: 我们的生意模式跟别人很不一样。我们主要抓效率，不像他们那样一心想着做大做强。一般来说，人多了就觉得能同时搞很多项目，确实也能做到。同时推进各种业务，针对不同客户搞不同的产品和服务层级，配销售团队，把组织架构搭得很复杂。
text_es: Nosotros manejamos un negocio muy diferente. Nos enfocamos en la eficiencia, no en el crecimiento. Ellos se enfocan en el crecimiento. Entonces típicamente, cuando tienes mucha gente, crees que puedes hacer más cosas a la vez, y probablemente sí puedas. Haces más cosas al mismo tiempo, tienes diferentes ofertas para diferentes personas, diferentes niveles, vendedores, y todas esas cosas que van armando una organización.
context: Lenny asks Jason how 37signals can have similar customer numbers to much larger competitors like Asana (1600 employees) and Slack (2500 employees) while maintaining only 75 employees and high profitability. Jason explains that their business philosophy fundamentally differs from their competitors - they prioritize operational efficiency over rapid growth, which allows them to serve customers effectively with a much smaller team.
vocabulary_highlights: build up an organization, different tiers

speaker: Jason Fried
text: What that allows us to do is to just build one product, do a really nice job, keep it tight, and simple, and clear, and not have the complexity that comes with trying to service and satisfy so many different kinds of companies at different price levels with different price points and different expectations.
text_ko: 그렇게 하면 저희는 한 가지 제품(product)만 만들어서 정말 잘 다듬고, 깔끔하고 단순하며 명확하게 유지할 수 있어요. 여러 가격대(price levels)나 가격 포인트(price points), 기대치가 다른 다양한 회사들을 만족시키려다 보면 생기는 복잡함이 없거든요.
text_zh: 这样我们就能专心做好一个产品，把它做得特别棒，保持精简、简单、清晰，不用搞得那么复杂——不用去服务和满足各种不同类型的公司，不同的价位，不同的价格点，不同的期望值。
text_es: Lo que eso nos permite hacer es enfocarnos en construir un solo producto, hacerlo realmente bien, mantenerlo simple y claro, sin toda esa complejidad que viene cuando tratas de atender y satisfacer a tantos tipos diferentes de empresas con distintos niveles de precios, diferentes price points y expectativas completamente distintas.
context: Jason continues explaining why 37signals can operate with far fewer employees than competitors. He describes their pricing strategy where no customer can pay more than $299 regardless of company size, which eliminates the need for complex enterprise sales processes, multiple product tiers, and extensive support infrastructure that typically require large teams.
vocabulary_highlights: keep it tight, service and satisfy

speaker: Jason Fried
text: If you think about all of the space between a small business and a massive, huge unicorn-y business, there's so much room there that you could normally find your own way, and slide into a slot or a place that makes sense for you. But if you're venture-backed, you just don't even have the opportunity. You blow right past those, or they want you to blow right past those.
text_ko: 작은 사업과 엄청 큰 유니콘 같은 기업(unicorn) 사이를 생각해보면, 그 사이에는 스스로 길을 찾고 자신에게 맞는 틈새나 자리를 찾아 들어갈 수 있을 만큼 여지가 정말 많아요. 그런데 벤처 투자를 받은(venture-backed) 회사라면 그런 기회조차 없어요. 그 사이를 그냥 지나쳐 버리게 되거나, 투자자들이 그렇게 하길 바라기도 해요.
text_zh: 你想想，从小企业到那种超大规模的独角兽企业之间，其实有很大的发展空间，正常情况下你完全可以找到适合自己的位置，慢慢发展到一个合适的规模。但是如果你拿了风投的钱，就根本没有这个机会了。你要么直接跳过这些阶段，要么投资人就是希望你跳过这些阶段。
text_es: Si te pones a pensar en todo el espacio que hay entre un negocio pequeño y una empresa gigantesca tipo unicornio (unicorn), hay muchísimo lugar ahí donde normalmente podrías encontrar tu propio camino y meterte en un nicho o posición que te funcione. Pero si tienes capital de riesgo (venture capital), simplemente no tienes ni la oportunidad. Te saltas todas esas opciones de una, o ellos quieren que te las saltes.
context: Lenny asks Jason about when raising venture capital makes sense versus bootstrapping. Jason argues that venture funding severely limits a company's options because investors require massive growth and unicorn-level outcomes. He explains that there are many profitable business models between small businesses and billion-dollar companies, but venture-backed companies must skip over these sustainable options.
vocabulary_highlights: slide into a slot, blow right past those, unicorn-y business
topics: Fundraising, Starting a Company, Strategy & Planning

speaker: Jason Fried
text: The reason I think it's great for entrepreneurs to start bootstrapping is because they just have more practice making money, and they get better, and better, and better at the fundamental skill you need to have ultimately to run a successful business, which is to make money.
text_ko: 제가 창업자들이 부트스트래핑(bootstrapping)으로 시작하는 걸 좋다고 생각하는 이유는, 실제로 수익을 내보는 연습을 더 많이 하게 되고 그 과정에서 수익 창출 능력이 계속해서 더 좋아지기 때문이에요. 결국 성공적인 사업을 운영하려면 가장 근본적인 기술이 수익을 창출하는 능력인데, 부트스트래핑을 통해 그 기술을 반복해서 단련할 수 있어요.
text_zh: 我觉得创业者一开始自力更生(bootstrapping)特别好，因为这样他们赚钱的实战经验更多，会越来越熟练，越来越擅长这个最核心的技能——毕竟要想把生意做成功，说到底还是得会赚钱。
text_es: La razón por la que creo que es genial que los emprendedores empiecen haciendo bootstrapping es porque así practican más el arte de generar dinero, y van mejorando cada vez más en la habilidad fundamental que necesitas para manejar un negocio exitoso, que es precisamente eso: hacer dinero.
context: Jason explains why he advocates for bootstrapping over raising venture capital. He argues that bootstrapped entrepreneurs develop crucial money-making skills through constant practice, while venture-funded companies often become skilled at spending money rather than generating profit. This fundamental difference in experience affects a company's ability to eventually become profitable when investor funding becomes scarce.

speaker: Jason Fried
text: Starting a business is actually way easier than staying in business. Now, none of it's easy, so I want to be supportive of people who are starting businesses. But they should know that that's actually not the hard part. Literally tomorrow, I can start a new business. You can come up with a name, and you can make a thing, and you can put in the app store, and you can sell it for two bucks, and you've got a business going.
text_ko: 사업을 시작하는 건 사실 사업을 유지하는 것보다 훨씬 쉬워요. 근데 그렇다고 쉬운 게 하나도 없는 건 맞아서, 창업하는 사람들을 응원하고 싶어요. 다만 그들이 알아야 할 건, 그게 진짜 어려운 부분은 아니라는 거예요. 말 그대로 내일 당장이라도 새 사업을 시작할 수 있어요. 이름 짓고, 뭔가 하나 만들어서 앱스토어(App Store)에 올리고 2달러에 팔면 그걸로 사업이 되는 거예요.
text_zh: 创业其实比守业要容易得多。当然，这些都不简单，我也很支持那些正在创业的人。但他们得知道，创业真的不是最难的那一步。说白了，明天我就能开个新公司。你想个名字，做个产品，放到应用商店(app store)里，卖个两美金，生意就算开张了。
text_es: Montar un negocio en realidad es mucho más fácil que mantenerse en el mercado. Ahora, que nada de esto es fácil, ¿eh? Quiero apoyar a la gente que está empezando negocios. Pero tienen que saber que esa parte no es la más difícil. Literalmente mañana puedo arrancar un negocio nuevo. Te inventas un nombre, haces algo, lo subes a la tienda de aplicaciones, lo vendes por dos dólares, y ya tienes un negocio funcionando.
context: Jason introduces his concept of 'stay ups' versus 'startups' when discussing business sustainability. He argues that while the startup world celebrates launching new businesses, the real challenge lies in maintaining a business over time through competition, employee management, and market changes. This perspective reflects his focus on long-term business sustainability rather than initial launch success.
vocabulary_highlights: stay ups

speaker: Jason Fried
text: I almost would be embarrassed by what someone would come in and look at, and go, 'Oh my God, you guys are missing so many opportunities here.' I'd be like, 'Yeah, I know. I know we are, but I'm totally fine with it.' But, there'd be this moment of judgment and reckoning with, 'Do you realize how much you're leaving on the table?'
text_ko: 누군가 들어와서 보고 “세상에, 여기서 얼마나 많은 기회를 놓치고 있네요” 라고 하면 거의 민망해요. 저는 “네, 알아요. 우리가 그렇게 하고 있는 거, 저도 알아요. 근데 전 괜찮아요” 라고 말할 것 같아요. 그런데 그런 순간에는 “자신들이 얼마나 많은 걸 그냥 놓아두고 있는지 아세요?” 라는 판단의 순간과 마주하게 되죠.
text_zh: 要是有人进来看了我们的情况，然后说"天哪，你们错过了这么多机会"，我都觉得有点不好意思。我会说"对，我知道，我们确实错过了不少，但我完全能接受。" 不过那一刻还是会有点被人指指点点的感觉，人家会问"你们知道自己白白浪费了多少机会吗？"
text_es: Casi me daría pena que alguien viniera, echara un vistazo y dijera: "¡Dios mío, se están perdiendo un montón de oportunidades aquí!" Y yo estaría como: "Sí, ya lo sé. Sé que es así, pero estoy totalmente tranquilo con eso." Pero habría ese momento de juicio y ajuste de cuentas con: "¿Te das cuenta de todo el dinero que estás dejando sobre la mesa?"
context: Lenny asks Jason what he thinks would happen if someone else ran 37signals. Jason reflects on how a different leader would likely focus on growth opportunities that he consciously ignores, such as multiple pricing tiers, specialized product versions, and aggressive marketing spend. He acknowledges these missed opportunities but expresses contentment with their current approach of intentional simplicity.
vocabulary_highlights: moment of judgment and reckoning, leaving on the table

speaker: Jason Fried
text: Work expands to fill the time available. So for us it's about appetite. So the idea of appetites, maxing things out at six weeks, two people max, and then there's a lot of other details, and I could go on for an hour about Shape Up, people can read about it.
text_ko: 일은 주어진 시간만큼 늘어나기 마련이에요. 그래서 우리에게는 욕구가 중요해요. 그래서 최대 6주 동안 두 명이서 최대한 밀어붙이는 아이디어가 필요하고, 그 외에도 많은 세부사항이 있어요. 'Shape Up'에 대해 한 시간 동안 이야기할 수 있지만, 사람들은 그걸 읽어보면 될 것 같아요.
text_zh: 工作量总是会填满你给它的时间。所以对我们来说关键是要控制胃口。就是这个胃口的概念，最多六周，最多两个人，把事情控制在这个范围内，还有很多其他细节，我可以讲一个小时关于Shape Up这套方法，大家可以去了解一下。
text_es: El trabajo siempre se expande para ocupar todo el tiempo que tienes disponible. Entonces para nosotros se trata del apetito. O sea, la idea de los apetitos, limitando todo a máximo seis semanas, máximo dos personas, y después hay un montón de otros detalles. Me podría pasar una hora hablando de Shape Up, pero la gente puede leer sobre eso.
context: Jason explains 37signals' Shape Up development methodology to Lenny. He describes how they use 'appetites' instead of estimates - setting a fixed time budget (maximum six weeks) and team size (two people) for any feature, rather than estimating how long work will take. This approach prevents projects from extending indefinitely and forces teams to find the simplest effective solution within constraints.
vocabulary_highlights: work expands to fill the time available, maxing things out

speaker: Jason Lemkin
speaker_expertise: Sales Strategy, B2B SaaS, Community Building
text: The beauty to founders is they don't need help in the middle. You can be 10 times better in the middle than any sales rep at your bigger competitor. If you're running, I am just making up CRM, but if you're running a new CRM startup, you can run circles around 98% of the sales reps at Salesforce or HubSpot. They have the brand, they have the partners, they have the integrations, but they cannot answer the questions you can answer.
text_ko: 창업자에게 멋진 점은 중간에 도움을 받을 필요가 없다는 거예요. 당신이 경쟁사보다 중간 단계에서 10배 더 나은 성과를 낼 수 있어요. 예를 들어, 새로운 CRM 스타트업을 운영하고 있다면, Salesforce나 HubSpot의 98% 영업사원보다 훨씬 더 앞서 나갈 수 있어요. 그들은 브랜드도 있고, 파트너도 있고, 통합도 되어 있지만, 당신이 대답할 수 있는 질문에는 답을 못해요.
text_zh: 创始人的优势就在于中间环节不需要别人帮忙。在中间这块，你可以比大竞争对手的任何销售都强十倍。打个比方，假如你在做一个新的CRM创业项目，你绝对可以秒杀Salesforce或者HubSpot那边98%的销售。他们是有品牌、有合作伙伴、有各种集成，但是你能回答的问题，他们根本答不上来。
text_es: Lo genial de los fundadores es que no necesitan ayuda en el proceso intermedio. Puedes ser 10 veces mejor en esa parte que cualquier vendedor de tu competencia más grande. Si estás manejando, no sé, digamos un CRM, pero si tienes una startup nueva de CRM, puedes darles mil vueltas al 98% of los vendedores de Salesforce o HubSpot. Ellos tienen la marca, tienen los socios, tienen las integraciones, pero no pueden contestar las preguntas que tú sí puedes contestar.
context: Lenny asks Jason to clarify what he means by 'middlers' in sales conversations. Jason explains that founders are naturally good at the middle part of sales conversations - they can expertly discuss their product and solve customer problems, even if they're not great at opening or closing deals. He argues that founders have a huge advantage over sales reps at bigger competitors because they have deep product knowledge that most sales reps lack.
vocabulary_highlights: run circles around, cannot answer the questions

speaker: Jason Lemkin
speaker_expertise: Sales Strategy, B2B SaaS, Community Building
text: Those first couple reps have to be people you would buy your own product from. That's it. Now we can talk about other criteria. We can talk about normalizing for deal size. We can talk about industry expertise. We can talk about all this kind of stuff, but when you go out as a first time founder and interview 30 reps, and you're going to have to interview 30, and 20 are just going to break your brain because they don't do any work and they don't do any prep and they didn't even go to your website.
text_ko: 처음 몇 명의 영업 담당자(reps)는 당신이 ‘이 사람한테서 직접 제품을 살 것 같다’고 느낄 정도의 사람들이어야 해요. 그게 전부예요. 그다음에 다른 기준들을 얘기할 수 있죠. 거래 규모(deal size)를 보정하는 문제라든가, 산업 전문성(industry expertise) 같은 것들을요. 온갖 얘기를 할 수 있지만, 첫 창업자(first-time founder)로서 나가서 30명의 영업 담당자(reps)를 인터뷰해야 한다면 — 실제로 30명을 다 인터뷰해야 할 거예요 — 그중 20명은 일을 안 하고 준비도 안 하고 심지어 웹사이트조차 안 봐서 당신을 완전히 골치 아프게 만들 거예요.
text_zh: 头几个销售(reps)必须得是那种你自己都愿意从他们那买产品的人，就这么简单。然后咱们再谈其他标准也不迟。咱们可以聊怎么按照单子大小来衡量，可以聊行业专业度，可以聊各种各样的东西，但是作为第一次创业的创始人，你出去面试30个销售(reps)的时候——而且你确实得面试30个——其中20个会直接把你气疯，因为他们啥功课都不做，啥准备都没有，连你的网站都懒得看一眼。
text_es: Esos primeros vendedores tienen que ser gente a la que tú mismo le comprarías tu producto. Así de simple. Ya después podemos hablar de otros criterios. Podemos hablar de ajustar por el tamaño del deal. Podemos hablar de experiencia en la industria. De todo ese rollo, pero cuando sales como fundador primerizo y entrevistas a 30 vendedores, y vas a tener que entrevistar a 30, te vas a dar cuenta de que 20 te van a freír la cabeza porque no hacen nada de trabajo, no se preparan para nada y ni siquiera se molestaron en ver tu página web.
context: Lenny asks about signs that indicate it's time to hire your first salesperson. Jason shares his key hiring criterion for the first two sales reps - they must be people you would actually buy your own product from. He explains that most founders will need to interview around 30 candidates, with 20 being completely unprepared and only 1-2 being truly magical hires who understand the product deeply.
vocabulary_highlights: break your brain, normalizing for

speaker: Jason Lemkin
speaker_expertise: Sales Strategy, B2B SaaS, Community Building
text: You need two sales reps hitting quota closing deals before you're ready to hire a manager for them. Almost all VPs of sales, their job is to take you from rep three to 300, to take you from three to 300, to take something that's just starting to repeat, a script that's just starting to work, leads that are just starting to come in.
text_ko: 관리자를 뽑을 준비가 되려면 쿼터(quota)를 달성하고 계약을 성사시키는 영업 담당자(sales reps) 두 명이 있어야 해요. 거의 모든 영업 부사장(VP of Sales)의 역할은 영업 담당자 3명에서 300명으로 키우는 것, 즉 이제 막 반복되기 시작한 상황—효과가 나기 시작한 영업 스크립트(script)와 리드(leads)가 들어오기 시작한 상태—을 확장하는 일이에요.
text_zh: 你得先有两个销售能完成业绩指标、能成单，这时候才适合给他们配个经理。几乎所有的销售VP，他们的活儿就是带着你从第3个销售做到300个，从3个人的小团队扩展到300人，把刚开始有点起色的业务、刚开始管用的话术(script)、刚开始进来的线索(leads)真正做起规模来。
text_es: Necesitas dos vendedores que estén cumpliendo su cuota y cerrando negocios antes de estar listo para contratarles un gerente. Casi todos los VPs de ventas, su trabajo es llevarte del vendedor tres al 300, llevarte de tres a 300, tomar algo que apenas está empezando a repetirse, un guión que apenas está empezando a funcionar, prospectos (leads) que apenas están empezando a llegar.
context: Lenny asks about the appropriate level and seniority for first sales hires, specifically about the common mistake of hiring a VP of sales too early. Jason explains that you need two successful individual contributor reps before hiring a sales manager. He describes the VP of sales role as scaling from 3 to 300 reps, not finding initial product-market fit.
vocabulary_highlights: hitting quota, starting to repeat

speaker: Jason Lemkin
speaker_expertise: Sales Strategy, B2B SaaS, Community Building
text: If you hire a VP of sales before then, you're asking them to find product market fit to be the first rep, to be the second rep and scale it all at the same time. It's mission impossible to do all four at the same time. So that's the biggest mistake is, Lenny, I can't get sales going at my company. I can't do it, but I raised $4 million in my C+ round. I'm going to go out and hire the VP of sales. That VP of sales will not be there in eight months.
text_ko: 그 시점 이전에 영업 부사장(VP of Sales)을 뽑으면, 그 사람에게 제품-시장 적합성(product-market fit)을 찾아야 하고, 첫 영업 담당자(first rep)로 뛰어야 하고, 두 번째 영업 담당자(second rep) 역할도 하면서 동시에 조직을 확장(scale)하라고 요구하는 셈이에요. 네 가지를 한꺼번에 해내라고 하는 건 사실상 불가능해요. 그래서 가장 큰 실수는 이런 거예요. "레니, 우리 회사 영업이 안 돼요. 제가 못하겠어요. 근데 C+ 라운드(C+ round)에서 400만 달러를 모았으니 영업 부사장(VP of Sales)을 바로 뽑을게요." 그런데 그 영업 부사장은 8개월도 못 버틸 거예요.
text_zh: 如果你在那之前就招一个销售VP，那你就是让他们既要找产品市场匹配(product market fit)，又要当第一个销售，还要当第二个销售，同时还得把整个团队规模化。这四件事同时做，简直是不可能完成的任务。所以最大的错误就是，Lenny，我公司的销售搞不起来，我自己搞不定，但我C+轮融了400万美金，那我就出去招个销售VP吧。这个销售VP八个月内肯定走人。
text_es: Si contratas a un VP de ventas antes de ese momento, le estás pidiendo que encuentre el product market fit, que sea el primer vendedor, que sea el segundo vendedor y que escale todo al mismo tiempo. Es una misión imposible hacer las cuatro cosas a la vez. Ese es el error más grande: "Lenny, no logro que arranquen las ventas en mi empresa. No puedo hacerlo, pero levanté 4 millones de dólares en mi ronda C+. Voy a salir a contratar un VP de ventas." Ese VP de ventas no va a estar ahí en ocho meses.
context: Lenny continues asking about when to hire a VP of sales. Jason emphasizes why hiring a VP of sales too early always fails - you're asking one person to simultaneously discover product-market fit, be the first successful rep, train a second rep, and build scalable processes. He warns that this approach typically results in the VP leaving within eight months and burning through significant cash.
vocabulary_highlights: mission impossible, C+ round

speaker: Jason Lemkin
speaker_expertise: Sales Strategy, B2B SaaS, Community Building
text: Here's the mistake that 99% of founders and sales reps make. We're not really selling in B2B, we're solving problems. Our job as sales reps in SaaS is to not sell a used car, okay? We are selling a Tesla Model 3 performance. It has competition, I might not need it this week, but it's pretty darn good. Let me help you get you into that Model 3 performance today.
text_ko: 창업자랑 영업사원 중 99%가 하는 실수가 있어요. 우리는 B2B(B2B)에서 단순히 '파는' 사람이 아니라 문제를 해결하는 사람인 걸 몰라요. SaaS(SaaS)에서 영업사원으로서 우리의 역할은 중고차를 팔아치우는 게 아니에요. 우리는 테슬라 모델 3 퍼포먼스(Tesla Model 3 Performance)를 파는 거예요. 경쟁은 있겠고, 이번 주에 꼭 필요하지 않을 수도 있지만, 이건 정말 좋은 선택이에요. 오늘 제가 그 모델 3 퍼포먼스에 타실 수 있게 도와드릴게요.
text_zh: 99%的创始人和销售都犯这个错误。在B2B里，我们其实不是在卖东西，而是在解决问题。我们做SaaS销售的，不是在卖二手车，明白吧？我们卖的是特斯拉Model 3高性能版。虽然有竞争对手，我这周可能也不急着要，但这车确实够棒的。让我今天就帮你拿下这台Model 3高性能版。
text_es: Aquí está el error que comete el 99% de los fundadores y vendedores. En B2B no estamos vendiendo realmente, estamos resolviendo problemas. Nuestro trabajo como vendedores en SaaS no es vender un carro usado, ¿vale? Estamos vendiendo un Tesla Model 3 performance. Tiene competencia, puede que no lo necesite esta semana, pero está padrísimo. Déjeme ayudarle a conseguir ese Model 3 performance hoy mismo.
context: During a discussion about interview techniques for sales reps, Jason explains the fundamental mindset shift needed in B2B sales. He argues that SaaS companies aren't selling commodities but solving meaningful problems, comparing it to selling a high-quality Tesla rather than using manipulative used car tactics. This perspective is crucial for both founders and sales reps to understand.
vocabulary_highlights: pretty darn good, get you into

speaker: Jason Lemkin
speaker_expertise: Sales Strategy, B2B SaaS, Community Building
text: The first three months of a new rep, you're lucky if they can close as much as their take-home pay is, their OT. And so, in the really early days, my early, early day comp plan is, look, your first three months, you keep a hundred percent of what you close. Of course, that's not profitable for the business, but you've got to invest in them, right?
text_ko: 신입 영업사원이 처음 세 달 동안에 성사시키는 실적이 실수령액(take-home pay), 그러니까 OT(on-target earnings)만큼 나와도 운이 좋은 거예요. 그래서 정말 초창기에는 제 보상 플랜(comp plan, compensation plan)이 이렇습니다. 보세요, 처음 세 달 동안 성사시킨 건 전부 100% 가져가세요. 물론 회사 입장에서는 이게 수익이 나는 구조는 아니지만, 그 사람들에게는 투자를 해야 해요.
text_zh: 新销售的前三个月，他们能成交的金额跟他们拿到手的工资差不多就不错了。所以在最开始那段时间，我的薪酬方案(comp plan)是这样的：头三个月，你成交多少全归你。当然这样对公司来说肯定是不赚钱的，但你得先投资培养他们，对吧？
text_es: Los primeros tres meses de un vendedor nuevo, con suerte van a cerrar ventas por lo que ganan neto, su salario base. Entonces, en los primeros días, mi plan de comisiones (comp plan) desde el inicio es: mira, tus primeros tres meses, te quedas con el cien por ciento de lo que cierres. Claro, eso no es rentable para el negocio, pero tienes que invertir en ellos, ¿no?
context: Lenny asks about compensation and quota structure for early sales hires. Jason explains his unconventional approach of letting new reps keep 100% of what they close in their first quarter. He acknowledges this isn't immediately profitable but argues it's necessary investment to help reps get started and build confidence while learning the product.
vocabulary_highlights: take-home pay, OT, put supper on the stove

speaker: Jason Lemkin
speaker_expertise: Sales Strategy, B2B SaaS, Community Building
text: The magical thing at the high level that it compounds, if you have a self-service model, a PLG model, I actually think the number one most important metric is churn. It's going to this churn, churn, churn, churn. And when I meet any startup for investing or anything, if the churn is not top decile for a low end product, I'm always out. It's almost unsolvable.
text_ko: 높은 수준에서 복리처럼 불어나는 마법 같은 건, 셀프 서비스 모델(self-service model)이나 PLG 모델(PLG model)이 있을 때인데, 사실 가장 중요한 지표는 이탈률(churn)이라고 생각해요. 계속 이탈, 이탈, 이탈이에요. 그래서 투자나 미팅으로 스타트업을 만날 때 저가형 제품(low-end product)의 이탈률이 상위 10%(top decile)에 들지 않으면 저는 항상 손 떼요. 거의 해결 불가능하다고 봐요.
text_zh: 高层面上有个神奇的地方，就是复合效应。如果你做的是自助服务模式，PLG模式(product-led growth)，我觉得最重要的指标其实是流失率(churn)。就是不断地流失、流失、流失。我见任何创业公司，不管是投资还是别的，如果是低端产品但流失率不在前10%，我基本就不考虑了。这个问题几乎没法解决。
text_es: Lo increíble a alto nivel es que se compone, si tienes un modelo de autoservicio, un modelo PLG (product-led growth), yo creo que la métrica más importante de todas es el churn. Todo se reduce al churn, churn, churn, churn. Y cuando me reúno con cualquier startup para invertir o lo que sea, si el churn no está en el decil superior para un producto de gama baja, siempre paso. Es casi imposible de resolver.
context: Lenny asks about product teams taking on P&L responsibilities and revenue goals. Jason discusses the importance of focusing on metrics that compound over time rather than short-term revenue optimization. He emphasizes that for PLG companies, churn is the most critical metric because high churn rates (3-4% monthly) are nearly impossible to overcome and prevent building a sustainable billion-dollar business.
vocabulary_highlights: top decile, almost unsolvable
topics: Product Management, Growth & Marketing, Strategy & Planning

speaker: Jason Shah
speaker_expertise: Product Management, Leadership Development, Team Building
text: Pushback is, I couldn't imagine a word more viscerally that makes you feel like you're sort of physically going against what somebody else wants, and it gears people into a mindset of then, well, how should I push back. It starts from a place of I need to disagree, I need to say no. It's a very negative mindset, purely based on the word that has come to label a behavior that alternatively could be about how do I shift the direction on something, or how do I help the business actually succeed when I disagree with somebody about something, and that's a very different mindset.
text_ko: 푸시백(pushback)이라는 말만큼 사람들로 하여금 '상대가 원하는 것에 그냥 몸으로 맞서는 느낌'을 주는 단어는 상상하기 어려워요. 그 말 자체가 사람들을 '그럼 어떻게 푸시백해야 하지?'라는 마인드셋(mindset)으로 몰아넣죠. 즉 처음부터 '반대해야 해, 아니라고 말해야 해'라는 출발점에서 시작하는 아주 부정적인 사고방식이에요. 그런데 사실 그 단어로 규정된 행동은 달리 보면 '어떻게 방향을 바꿀 수 있을까'나 '누군가와 의견이 다를 때 어떻게 하면 비즈니스가 실제로 성공하도록 도울 수 있을까' 같은 얘기일 수도 있어요. 그건 완전히 다른 마인드셋이에요.
text_zh: Pushback这个词，我想不出还有什么词能让人这么强烈地感觉到你在跟别人硬碰硬，而且一听到这个词，大家就会想"那我该怎么怼回去"。一开始就是抱着"我得反对，我得说不"的心态。这完全就是个负面思维，就因为用了这么个词来形容一种行为。其实换个角度想，这种行为也可以是"我怎么调整一下方向"，或者"当我跟别人意见不一致的时候，怎么帮公司真正做成事"，这样想就完全不一样了。
text_es: La resistencia o el "pushback", no se me ocurre una palabra que te haga sentir más visceralmente que estás yendo físicamente en contra de lo que otra persona quiere, y eso mete a la gente en una mentalidad de "bueno, ¿cómo debería resistirme?". Parte de un lugar de "necesito estar en desacuerdo, necesito decir que no". Es una mentalidad muy negativa, basada puramente en la palabra que ha llegado a etiquetar un comportamiento que, por el contrario, podría ser más bien "¿cómo redirijo algo?" o "¿cómo ayudo realmente al negocio a tener éxito cuando no estoy de acuerdo con alguien sobre algo?", y esa es una mentalidad muy diferente.
context: Lenny asks Jason about how to effectively push back on CEOs and founders when disagreeing with their decisions. Jason argues that the term 'pushback' itself creates a problematic framing because it sets up an adversarial mindset focused on disagreement and saying no, when the real goal should be helping the business succeed through constructive redirection.
vocabulary_highlights: more viscerally, gears people into a mindset, shift the direction

speaker: Jason Shah
speaker_expertise: Product Management, Leadership Development, Team Building
text: I mean, I think the biggest surprise to me, despite what we were just talking about, was how big some products have gotten without kind of the traditional either product manager role or without the playbooks that we're so used to from the last 20 years of the internet. And so, for example, Uniswap has done more daily volume on certain days than Coinbase, and Uniswap is about a hundred people versus 5,000-plus at Coinbase, right? So, that's astounding to me.
text_ko: 제 생각엔, 방금 얘기한 것과는 별개로 가장 놀라웠던 건 전통적인 제품 관리자 역할(product manager role)이나 지난 20년간 인터넷 시대에 우리가 익숙해진 플레이북(playbooks) 없이도 어떤 제품들이 이렇게 커졌다는 점이에요. 예를 들어 어떤 날에는 유니스왑(Uniswap)이 코인베이스(Coinbase)보다 하루 거래량(daily volume)이 더 많았고, 유니스왑은 인원이 약 100명인 반면 코인베이스는 5,000명 이상이잖아요. 그게 정말 놀랍더라고요.
text_zh: 我觉得最让我意外的是，尽管我们刚才说了那些，但有些产品居然能做得这么大，完全没有传统的产品经理(product manager)角色，也没有用我们过去20年互联网时代那套成熟的打法。比如说，Uniswap某些天的日交易量甚至超过了Coinbase，但Uniswap才100来个人，Coinbase可是5000多人的团队，对吧？这真的太令人震惊了。
text_es: Mira, creo que lo que más me sorprendió, a pesar de lo que acabamos de hablar, fue ver qué tan grandes se han vuelto algunos productos sin tener ese rol tradicional de product manager o sin los manuales (playbooks) a los que nos acostumbramos en estos últimos 20 años de internet. Por ejemplo, Uniswap ha manejado más volumen diario que Coinbase en ciertos días, y Uniswap tiene como cien personas comparado con las más de 5,000 de Coinbase, ¿no? Eso me parece impresionante.
context: Lenny asks Jason what has surprised him most about working as a PM in Web3. Jason explains that he's been amazed by how large Web3 products have grown without traditional product management roles or established internet playbooks. He uses Uniswap as an example - a decentralized exchange that sometimes processes more daily trading volume than Coinbase despite having only 100 employees compared to Coinbase's 5,000+ workforce.
vocabulary_highlights: the playbooks that we're so used to, astounding to me

speaker: Jason Shah
speaker_expertise: Product Management, Leadership Development, Team Building
text: I think it's all about a focus on progress and moving forward. We saw this at Airbnb when the business had a draw down in revenue, and I know you'd covered this with Sanchan recently, right? It was 85, 90% revenue and you didn't know when it was going to turn around, right? It's not just like, 'Oh yeah, this will come back in six months and we can just keep plowing forward.' But I think what worked was making progress and actually focusing on product and your customers, and ultimately if you hire the right people who are motivated for the right reasons, I think that recipe keeps people highly motivated and highly effective at building for when things do eventually turn around.
text_ko: 진짜 중요한 건 지속적인 발전과 앞으로 나아가는 거라고 생각해요. Airbnb에서도 매출이 줄어들었을 때 그런 걸 경험했죠. 최근에 산찬이랑 이 얘기 나눴던 거 아시죠? 매출이 85%, 90%까지 떨어졌고, 언제 회복될지 전혀 알 수 없었어요. 단순히 '아, 6개월 후에 돌아올 거니까 그냥 계속 밀고 나가면 돼' 이런 게 아니었죠. 하지만 중요한 건 발전을 이루고, 제품과 고객에 집중하는 거였어요. 그리고 결국 올바른 이유로 동기부여가 된 사람들을 채용하면, 그런 조합이 사람들을 매우 동기부여하고 효과적으로 만들어서 상황이 좋아질 때를 대비할 수 있게 해준다고 생각해요.
text_zh: 我觉得关键就是要专注于进步，不断往前走。你看Airbnb那会儿营收大跌的时候就是这样，我知道你最近跟三展也聊过这事儿，对吧？当时收入掉了85%、90%，完全不知道什么时候能回转，对不对？这不是说"哦没事，六个月后就能好转，我们继续埋头干就行了"那么简单。但我觉得有效的做法就是持续取得进展，真正把重心放在产品和客户身上。最终如果你招到了对的人，他们的动机也是对的，我觉得这个配方就能让大家保持很高的积极性和执行力，为最终的回转做好准备。
text_es: Creo que todo se trata de enfocarse en el progreso y seguir adelante. Lo vimos en Airbnb cuando el negocio tuvo una caída fuerte en ingresos, y sé que hablaste de esto con Sanchan hace poco, ¿verdad? Fue una caída del 85, 90% de los ingresos y no sabías cuándo se iba a recuperar, ¿no? No era como decir 'Ah sí, esto se va a recuperar en seis meses y podemos seguir adelante como si nada.' Pero creo que lo que funcionó fue hacer progreso real y enfocarse de verdad en el producto y en tus clientes, y al final del día, si contratas a las personas correctas que están motivadas por las razones correctas, creo que esa fórmula mantiene a la gente súper motivada y súper efectiva construyendo para cuando las cosas eventualmente se recuperen.
context: Lenny asks Jason how he's managed to keep teams focused and maintain morale during the recent crypto winter while working in Web3. Jason explains that the key to maintaining morale during difficult periods is making tangible progress rather than relying on speeches or external motivators. He references how Airbnb maintained team effectiveness during COVID when they lost 85-90% of their revenue by continuing to focus on product development and customer needs.
vocabulary_highlights: draw down in revenue, keep plowing forward

speaker: Jason Shah
