speaker_expertise: Product Management, Leadership Development, Team Building
text: I think Amazon was a place where you couldn't divorce business and product. You couldn't be a product manager without thinking about revenue growth, without thinking about go to market, and I really like that because as a startup founder doing product in a bigger company, it gave me the chance to exercise a lot of those skills.
text_ko: 아마존은 비즈니스와 제품을 떼어놓을 수 없는 곳이었어요. 프로덕트 매니저(product manager)라면 매출 성장(revenue growth)이나 출시 전략(go-to-market)을 고려하지 않고는 일할 수 없었어요. 저는 그런 점이 정말 좋았어요. 스타트업 창업자(startup founder)로서 더 큰 회사에서 제품을 다루며 그런 역량들을 많이 써볼 수 있었거든요.
text_zh: 我觉得在亚马逊，业务和产品是分不开的。你做产品经理不可能不考虑收入增长，不可能不想着怎么推向市场(go to market)，我特别喜欢这一点，因为作为一个创业者在大公司里做产品，这让我有机会锻炼了很多这方面的能力。
text_es: Creo que Amazon era un lugar donde no podías separar el negocio del producto. No podías ser product manager sin pensar en el crecimiento de ingresos, sin pensar en la estrategia de salida al mercado (go to market), y eso me gustaba mucho porque como fundador de startup haciendo producto en una empresa más grande, me daba la oportunidad de poner en práctica todas esas habilidades.
context: Lenny asks Jason which of the major companies he's worked at (Yammer, Microsoft, Amazon, Airbnb) has most influenced his approach to product management. Jason explains that Amazon had the biggest impact because it required PMs to integrate business thinking with product decisions. Unlike companies known for specific cultures (Google for engineering, Facebook for product), Amazon demanded that product managers consider revenue growth and go-to-market strategy as core responsibilities.
vocabulary_highlights: couldn't divorce business and product, exercise a lot of those skills

speaker: Jason Shah
speaker_expertise: Product Management, Leadership Development, Team Building
text: I think the working backwards process of establishing the long-term goal using a mechanism like a press release and the FAQs where every word matters, and even the FAQs, for what it's worth, there's a section for external FAQs that you would include for example as an appendix, but also internal FAQs that are meant to de-risk launch or raise the elephant in the room or dogs not barking as Amazon likes to call it often.
text_ko: 장기 목표를 설정할 때, 보도자료(press release)와 자주 묻는 질문(FAQs) 같은 방식을 활용해 뒤에서부터 작업하는 과정이 중요해요. 모든 단어가 중요하니까요. 외부 FAQ 섹션을 부록으로 포함할 수도 있고, 내부 FAQ는 출시 리스크를 줄이거나 문제를 미리 짚어보는 데 도움이 돼요. 아마존에서 자주 언급하는 '개가 짖지 않는 것(dogs not barking)'을 다루는 것도 포함되죠.
text_zh: 我觉得这种倒推的工作方式挺好的，就是先定下长远目标，然后用新闻稿(press release)和问答(FAQ)这些工具来梳理，每个字都很重要。说到问答部分，其实还挺有意思的，有对外的问答可以放在附录里，也有内部问答，主要是为了降低发布风险，或者把那些大家心照不宣的问题摆到台面上说清楚，亚马逊经常叫这个"不叫的狗"(dogs not barking)。
text_es: Creo que el proceso de trabajar hacia atrás, estableciendo la meta a largo plazo usando un mecanismo como un comunicado de prensa y las preguntas frecuentes donde cada palabra cuenta, y hasta en las FAQs, por cierto, hay una sección para FAQs externas que incluirías como un anexo, por ejemplo, pero también FAQs internas que están pensadas para reducir el riesgo del lanzamiento o sacar a la luz el elefante en la habitación o "perros que no ladran" (dogs not barking) como le gusta decir a Amazon.
context: Lenny asks Jason about concrete processes or tactics he learned from working at major companies. Jason describes Amazon's 'working backwards' process, which involves writing a press release and FAQ document before building a product. The press release forces clarity about the end goal, while the FAQ section addresses both external customer questions and internal concerns that could derisk the launch.
vocabulary_highlights: de-risk launch, raise the elephant in the room, dogs not barking

speaker: Jason Shah
speaker_expertise: Product Management, Leadership Development, Team Building
text: I think nothing is above them, they're in the details, and they adapt to new information and new situations. That's what I've seen the most that I've appreciated in the best leaders that I've gotten to either observe or work closely with.
text_ko: 저는 그분들이 잘난 체하지 않고 세부사항(details)까지 직접 챙기며, 새로운 정보(new information)와 새로운 상황(new situations)에 맞춰 잘 적응하는 모습을 가장 높이 평가했어요.
text_zh: 我觉得没有什么事情是他们不愿意亲自去做的，他们特别关注细节，而且能够根据新信息和新情况灵活调整。这是我在那些最优秀的领导者身上看到的最让我佩服的品质，不管是我观察到的还是跟我密切合作过的。
text_es: Creo que nada se les escapa, se fijan en los detalles, y se adaptan a información nueva y situaciones nuevas. Eso es lo que más he visto y valorado en los mejores líderes que he podido observar o con los que he trabajado de cerca.
context: Lenny asks Jason what he's learned about effective leadership from watching leaders at companies like Amazon, Airbnb, and others. Jason identifies three key traits he's observed in the best leaders: they don't consider any task beneath them (humility), they stay involved in detailed decisions rather than delegating everything, and they adapt their approach based on new information and changing circumstances rather than rigidly sticking to past playbooks.
vocabulary_highlights: nothing is above them

speaker: Jason Shah
speaker_expertise: Product Management, Leadership Development, Team Building
text: There's the framework I like is ladder versus map, and I think that you can be either person that any point in your life. Sometimes there's a bit of a set mindset that somebody might have one way or another, but I like ladder versus map. Ladder is about moving up. It's more influence, more power, a higher title, things like this, whereas map is I just want to go wherever's interesting, right?
text_ko: 제가 좋아하는 프레임워크는 사다리(ladder) 대 지도(map)예요. 인생의 어느 시점에든 누구나 두 유형 중 하나일 수 있고, 사람들 중에는 한쪽으로 고정돼 있다고 보는 경우도 있지만 저는 사다리 대 지도 구분이 마음에 들어요. 사다리는 위로 올라가는 거고, 영향력이나 권한, 더 높은 직함 같은 걸 얻는 쪽이에요. 반면 지도는 그냥 흥미로운 곳이면 어디든 가보고 싶어하는 거예요.
text_zh: 我很喜欢一个框架，叫做"阶梯型"对"地图型"，我觉得人在不同阶段可能是不同的类型。虽然有些人可能有固定的思维模式，但我还是喜欢用阶梯对地图这个概念。阶梯型就是往上爬，要更大的影响力、更多权力、更高的职位，这些东西。而地图型呢，就是哪里有意思我就去哪里，对吧？
text_es: Hay un esquema que me gusta mucho que es el de escalera versus mapa, y creo que puedes ser cualquiera de los dos en cualquier momento de tu vida. A veces hay gente que tiene una mentalidad más fija hacia un lado o el otro, pero a mí me gusta esta idea de escalera versus mapa. La escalera se trata de subir - más influencia, más poder, un puesto más alto, ese tipo de cosas. Mientras que el mapa es más como "yo solo quiero ir a donde sea interesante", ¿no?
context: Lenny asks Jason about his approach to career development, noting that Jason seems to follow his interests rather than climbing a traditional career ladder. Jason explains his 'ladder versus map' framework for thinking about careers. The ladder approach focuses on moving up hierarchically with more influence, power, and higher titles, while the map approach prioritizes following interesting opportunities regardless of traditional progression.
vocabulary_highlights: set mindset, go wherever's interesting

speaker: Jeanne DeWitt Grosser
text: With AI, it's just intensified because you have 10 players pursuing the same market opportunity and so your ability to actually bring the product to market to differentiate yourself from the competition has become more strategically important than it was previously.
text_ko: 인공지능(AI) 때문에 상황이 더 심해졌어요. 같은 시장 기회(market opportunity)를 10개 업체가 동시에 쫓고 있으니, 실제로 제품을 시장에 내놓는 능력, 즉 시장 출시(go-to-market) 역량으로 경쟁자들과 차별화하는 게 예전보다 훨씬 전략적으로 중요해졌어요.
text_zh: 有了AI以后，这种情况就更激烈了，因为现在有10个玩家都在争抢同一个市场机会，所以你能不能真正把产品推向市场、从竞争对手中脱颖而出，这个能力比以前更加关键了。
text_es: Con la IA, esto se ha intensificado muchísimo porque tienes 10 jugadores yendo tras la misma oportunidad de mercado, entonces tu capacidad para realmente sacar el producto al mercado y diferenciarte de la competencia se ha vuelto mucho más estratégicamente importante de lo que era antes.
context: Lenny mentions he's been getting many requests for go-to-market help lately. Jeanne explains why go-to-market has become increasingly critical in today's business environment. She points out that AI has created intense competition, with multiple companies often targeting the same opportunities, making effective product commercialization and competitive differentiation essential for success.
vocabulary_highlights: pursuing the same market opportunity, bring the product to market, strategically important

speaker: Jeanne DeWitt Grosser
text: 80% of customers buy to avoid pain or reduce risk as opposed to increased upside, which is a good thing for startup founders to understand. We all love to talk about the art of the possible, everything we're going to enable in the future, but that's often really a sale that's going to resonate with another founder.
text_ko: 고객의 약 80%는 더 큰 이익(upside)을 기대해서 사는 게 아니라, 고통을 피하거나 위험(risk)을 줄이기 위해 구매해요. 이건 스타트업 창업자들이 꼭 알아둬야 할 포인트예요. 우리 모두는 앞으로 가능해질 것들, 즉 '가능성의 예술(art of the possible)' 같은 얘기를 하길 좋아하지만, 그런 얘기는 실제로는 대개 다른 창업자에게만 공감되는 영업이에요.
text_zh: 80%的客户买产品都是为了避免麻烦或者降低风险，而不是为了获得更多收益，这一点创业者一定要搞清楚。我们都喜欢谈论各种可能性，谈论我们将来能实现什么，但这种销售话术(pitch)往往只对其他创业者有用。
text_es: El 80% de los clientes compran para evitarse dolores de cabeza o reducir riesgos, no tanto por conseguir más beneficios, y esto es algo súper importante que los fundadores de startups tienen que entender. A todos nos encanta hablar de las posibilidades infinitas, de todo lo que vamos a hacer posible en el futuro, pero la realidad es que ese discurso le va a llegar más que nada a otro fundador.
context: Lenny references advice from Jenna Abel about focusing on competitive advantages rather than just problem-solving. Jeanne shares a crucial insight about customer buying behavior - that most enterprise customers are primarily motivated by risk reduction rather than potential gains. She explains that while founders love discussing future possibilities and innovation, this approach mainly appeals to other founders rather than typical enterprise buyers.
vocabulary_highlights: art of the possible, resonate with

speaker: Jeanne DeWitt Grosser
text: The litmus test I have always given my sales team is if you are an account executive in my org and I put you in front of 10 engineers at our company, it should take them 10 minutes to figure out you aren't a product manager.
text_ko: 제가 영업팀에게 항상 제시하는 판별 기준은 이거예요. 우리 조직에서 영업 담당자(account executive)로 일하는 사람이 회사 엔지니어들(engineers) 10명 앞에 서 있으면, 그 사람들이 '이 사람은 제품 관리자(product manager)가 아니다'라는 걸 알아차리는 데 10분이면 충분해야 해요.
text_zh: 我一直给销售团队的试金石就是：如果你是我们组织里的客户经理(account executive)，我让你去跟公司10个工程师聊天，他们应该要花10分钟才能发现你其实不是产品经理。
text_es: La prueba definitiva que siempre les doy a mi equipo de ventas es esta: si eres ejecutivo de cuentas en mi organización y te pongo frente a 10 ingenieros de nuestra empresa, deberían tardar 10 minutos en darse cuenta de que no eres product manager.
context: Lenny mentions feedback from people who've worked with Jeanne about her superpower of building sales organizations that engineers appreciate. Jeanne explains her philosophy for creating sales teams that work well with technical teams. She describes her standard for sales excellence - that account executives should have such deep product knowledge and technical understanding that engineers would initially mistake them for product managers.
vocabulary_highlights: litmus test, account executive

speaker: Jeanne DeWitt Grosser
text: Often you're not only making that customer successful, but you're then taking all of that back to your product and engineering organization to figure out, okay, what was generalizable that we ought to build into our offering versus what is something that ultimately is going to be more of a professional service in the fullness of time.
text_ko: 대개 고객을 성공시키는 것뿐만 아니라, 그 경험을 다 프로덕트와 엔지니어링 조직(product and engineering organization)에 가져가서 어떤 부분은 일반화해서(generalizable) 우리 솔루션(offering)에 반영해야 하고, 어떤 부분은 시간이 지나면 결국 전문 서비스(professional service)로 남길지 판단하게 돼요.
text_zh: 很多时候你不光要帮客户把事情做成，还得把从客户那儿学到的东西带回产品和工程团队，然后大家一起琢磨，哪些东西是可以复制的、应该直接做到产品里去的，哪些东西到最后还是得走专业服务(professional service)这条路。
text_es: Muchas veces no solo estás logrando que ese cliente tenga éxito, sino que también llevas todo eso de vuelta a tu equipo de producto e ingeniería para analizar: "Oye, ¿qué de esto se puede generalizar y deberíamos integrar en nuestra oferta versus qué es algo que al final va a ser más bien un servicio profesional a largo plazo?"
context: Lenny asks about the biggest changes in go-to-market over recent years. Jeanne discusses how AI has made sales more consultative, with companies needing to help customers figure out what to change without knowing exactly what they need. She explains the rise of forward-deployed engineering (a rebranding of professional services) where teams work directly in customer environments to understand their needs and determine what should be built into the core product versus offered as services.
vocabulary_highlights: generalizable, in the fullness of time

speaker: Jeanne DeWitt Grosser
text: So it wasn't like this was a multi-quarter process, it actually moved super quickly and then again now we just sort of keep that agent manager working with the agent to get it to a point where we say, 'Hey, we're ready to roll.'
text_ko: 그러니까 몇 분기씩 걸리는 프로세스는 아니었고, 실제로 굉장히 빠르게 진행됐어요. 지금은 에이전트 매니저(agent manager)가 에이전트(agent)랑 계속 같이 작업해서 우리가 “이제 시작해도 되겠다”라고 말할 수 있는 수준까지 만들어 가고 있어요.
text_zh: 所以这个过程并不是要搞好几个季度那么久，实际上推进得特别快，然后现在我们就是让那个智能体管理器(agent manager)跟智能体(agent)一直配合，直到我们觉得"好了，可以上线了"。
text_es: O sea, no fue como un proceso de varios trimestres, la verdad es que se movió súper rápido y ahora simplemente mantenemos a ese gestor de agentes trabajando con el agente para llegar al punto donde decimos, "Oye, ya estamos listos para arrancar."
context: Lenny expresses amazement at Jeanne's story about reducing their SDR team from 10 people to 1 through AI automation. Jeanne explains the timeline and impact of implementing their lead agent - a single go-to-market engineer spent just 25-30% of their time over six weeks to create an AI system that could handle the workload of 10 sales development representatives, while maintaining the same conversion rates and improving response times.
vocabulary_highlights: multi-quarter process, ready to roll

speaker: Jeanne DeWitt Grosser
text: I struggle with sales comp because it's all about pay for performance, which I'm obviously a fan of, but it makes your organization less flexible because you basically have to decide 12 months in advance, these are things I value and particularly in this moment that could be different.
text_ko: 영업 보상(sales comp)에 대해선 고민이에요. 전적으로 성과 기반 보상(pay-for-performance)이라 저도 원칙적으로는 찬성이긴 한데, 조직의 유연성이 떨어져요. 사실상 1년 전에 '이게 우리가 중요하게 생각하는 것들이다'라고 미리 결정해야 하거든요. 특히 지금 같은 시기에는 그 우선순위가 달라질 수도 있는데요.
text_zh: 我对销售薪酬(sales comp)这块挺纠结的，因为它本质上就是按业绩付费，这个理念我肯定是支持的，但问题是这样一来你的组织就没那么灵活了，因为你基本上得提前12个月就定好，哪些东西是我看重的，特别是在现在这种时候，情况随时都可能变。
text_es: Me cuesta trabajo con la compensación de ventas porque se trata de pagar por resultados, lo cual obviamente me parece genial, pero hace que tu organización sea menos flexible porque básicamente tienes que decidir con 12 meses de anticipación cuáles son las cosas que valoras, y especialmente en este momento eso podría ser diferente.
context: Lenny asks about Jeanne's hot take on sales compensation and hiring practices. Jeanne explains her concern with traditional sales compensation structures. While she supports pay-for-performance principles, she argues that rigid annual compensation plans reduce organizational agility by forcing companies to predetermine priorities a year in advance, which can be problematic in rapidly changing markets where companies need to pivot quickly.
vocabulary_highlights: pay for performance, 12 months in advance

speaker: Jeff Weinstein
speaker_expertise: B2B SaaS, Product Management, User Experience
text: The moment the customer felt compelled enough to go out of their way to talk about some problem, that's a unbelievable gift. I will leave a meeting to just get one message back to them. If you're text message friendly with five or 10 of those, you are going to have so much direct signal that is infectious.
text_ko: 고객이 굳이 시간을 내서 어떤 문제에 대해 얘기할 만큼 마음이 동했다는 순간은 정말 믿기 힘든 선물이에요. 저는 그 한 통의 메시지를 전하려고 회의를 나가기도 해요. 그런 고객 다섯, 열 명과 문자(text message)로 편하게 지내면 직접적인 신호(direct signal)가 엄청나게 쌓이고, 그 신호들이 전염성 있게 퍼져요.
text_zh: 客户主动找上门来跟你聊他们遇到的问题，这简直是天大的礼物啊。碰到这种情况，我开会都能停下来，就为了马上回复他们一条消息。如果你能跟五到十个这样的客户保持微信联系，那你得到的第一手反馈(direct signal)就太有价值了，而且这种影响力会传染的。
text_es: En el momento en que el cliente se siente tan motivado que se toma la molestia de hablarte sobre algún problema, eso es un regalo increíble. Yo dejo una reunión solo para responderle un mensaje. Si tienes esa confianza por WhatsApp o mensaje con cinco o diez de esos clientes, vas a tener una información directa (direct signal) tan valiosa que es contagiosa.
context: Lenny is discussing Jeff's unique approach to customer engagement on Twitter. Jeff explains his philosophy about responding to customer feedback with extreme urgency and building direct relationships with customers. He emphasizes that when customers take time from their busy lives to communicate about your product, it represents an incredible opportunity that should be treated with the highest priority.
vocabulary_highlights: compelled enough, go out of their way, unbelievable gift, direct signal, infectious
topics: Customer Development, Communication Skills, Product Management

speaker: Jeff Weinstein
speaker_expertise: B2B SaaS, Product Management, User Experience
text: We show up four to eight people total pretend to be some company with some outcome problem. Rule one is you do not work at Stripe and rule two is we're not here to solve any problems. This is just about practicing empathy for the customer.
text_ko: 총 4~8명이 모여 어떤 회사를 가장하고 그 회사가 성과 문제(outcome problem)를 겪는 상황을 연기해요. 규칙 하나는 Stripe 직원이 아니어야 해요. 규칙 둘은 여기서 실제 문제를 해결하려고 온 게 아니에요. 이건 단지 고객에 대한 공감을 연습하는 자리예요.
text_zh: 我们会派四到八个人，假装是某个公司遇到了什么问题。第一条规则是你不能说自己在Stripe工作，第二条规则是我们不是来解决问题的。这个练习就是为了培养对客户的同理心。
text_es: Llegamos entre cuatro y ocho personas en total y fingimos ser una empresa con algún problema o resultado que necesitamos. La regla número uno es que no trabajas en Stripe y la regla número dos es que no estamos aquí para resolver ningún problema. Esto es solo para practicar la empatía con el cliente.
context: Lenny asks Jeff about study groups, a program he started at Stripe. Jeff explains how study groups work - they're sessions where Stripe employees roleplay as customers using their own products. Study groups are designed to help teams understand the customer experience by forcing employees to abandon their internal knowledge and approach products with fresh eyes, purely to build empathy rather than to critique or fix issues.
vocabulary_highlights: outcome problem, practicing empathy
topics: Product Management, Customer Development, Coaching & Development

speaker: Jeff Weinstein
speaker_expertise: B2B SaaS, Product Management, User Experience
text: Some of it was just the fact that I wasn't particularly good at the class and had to rationalize it for myself in some form. So in retrospect that sounds highfalutin, but at the time I just wasn't particularly good at the classes I was in.
text_ko: 사실 일부는 제가 그 수업을 특별히 잘하지 못해서였고, 그래서 제 나름대로 어떻게든 합리화했어요. 지금 돌이켜 보면 거창하게 들릴 수 있지만, 당시에는 그냥 제가 들었던 수업들을 잘 못했던 것뿐이에요.
text_zh: 有一部分原因说白了就是我在那门课上表现不怎么样，得给自己找个台阶下。现在回头看这话听起来挺装的，但当时我确实就是在上的那些课里表现平平。
text_es: Parte de eso era simplemente que no se me daba muy bien esa materia y tenía que justificármelo de alguna manera. Ahora en retrospectiva suena muy rebuscado, pero en ese momento simplemente no era muy bueno en las clases que estaba tomando.
context: Lenny asks Jeff about a quote where he chose to stay in classes he was potentially the worst at rather than dropping to easier levels. Jeff explains his unconventional academic approach and how his liberal arts education shaped his thinking. He's reflecting on how his willingness to stay in challenging situations, even when struggling, came from both necessity and a philosophical approach to learning that he developed in school.
vocabulary_highlights: rationalize it for myself, in retrospect, highfalutin, wasn't particularly good at

speaker: Jeff Weinstein
speaker_expertise: B2B SaaS, Product Management, User Experience
text: So I see the world as immediately we have just such opportunity to take action in front of us. We can be optimistic and go, go, go as soon as possible. I think that a lot of life is you get as much furniture as you've room in the house. We will do the work the night before it's due, so let's just make it due tomorrow.
text_ko: 저는 세상을 보면 바로 눈앞에 행동할 기회가 있다고 봐요. 낙관적으로 가능한 한 빨리 시작해서 계속 밀고 나가면 돼요. 인생의 많은 부분은 집에 들어갈 만큼 가구를 채워 넣는 것처럼, 가능한 만큼 이것저것 채워 넣는 거라고 생각해요. 우리는 다들 마감 전날 밤에 일을 하는 편이니까, 그러니 마감일을 그냥 내일로 정해버리자고요.
text_zh: 所以我觉得现在机会就摆在我们面前，我们应该保持乐观，马上行动起来。我觉得人生就是这样，你有多大房子就放多少家具。反正活儿都是截止前一晚才做完，那不如把截止时间定在明天。
text_es: Mira, yo veo que el mundo ahora mismo nos está poniendo oportunidades increíbles justo enfrente. Podemos ser optimistas y echarle ganas, arrancar ya mismo. Creo que en la vida pasa mucho eso de que uno llena la casa con todos los muebles que le caben. Siempre terminamos haciendo el trabajo la noche anterior a la entrega, entonces mejor pongamos la fecha límite para mañana.
context: Lenny asks Jeff to explain his philosophy of 'go, go, go ASAP plus optimistic, long-term compounding approach.' Jeff describes his belief in taking immediate action while maintaining optimism. He uses metaphors to explain how artificial urgency can drive productivity - comparing it to how work expands to fill available time, and suggesting that creating tighter deadlines can accelerate progress and create momentum.
vocabulary_highlights: take action in front of us, as much furniture as you've room in the house, make it due tomorrow
topics: Strategy & Planning, Decision Making, Leadership & Management

speaker: Jeff Weinstein
speaker_expertise: B2B SaaS, Product Management, User Experience
text: I think I'm really working backwards from failures in the past and avoiding them. And so maybe just a quick story. I started a company several years ago based on just a personal pet peeve of mine, which was I was a SQL analyst.
text_ko: 저는 과거의 실패들을 되돌아보며 거기서부터 역으로 접근해서 같은 실수를 피하려고 하는 것 같아요. 간단한 얘기 하나만 할게요. 몇 년 전에 제가 SQL 분석가(SQL analyst)로 일하면서 느꼈던 개인적인 불편함 때문에 회사를 하나 시작했어요.
text_zh: 我觉得我其实是在从过去的失败中吸取教训，然后尽量避免重蹈覆辙。简单讲个故事吧。几年前我创办了一家公司，完全是因为我个人的一个痛点，当时我是做SQL分析的。
text_es: Creo que realmente estoy trabajando al revés, partiendo de los fracasos del pasado para evitarlos. Te cuento rápido una historia. Hace varios años monté una empresa basándome en algo que me molestaba muchísimo a nivel personal, y es que yo era analista de SQL.
context: Lenny asks Jeff why craft and quality are so important to him in product development. Jeff explains that his obsession with craft comes from learning from past mistakes. He's about to share a story about a company he started that taught him important lessons about the difference between building something people like versus building something people truly need and will pay for.
vocabulary_highlights: working backwards from failures, personal pet peeve
topics: Starting a Company, Learning & Growth, Product Management

speaker: Jeff Weinstein
speaker_expertise: B2B SaaS, Product Management, User Experience
text: People don't really get out of bed for their second problem. They get out of bed for their first problem. And you have to carefully listen and not pitch your customer or your prospective customer as you're trying to figure this out.
text_ko: 사람들은 두 번째 문제 때문에 굳이 일어나지 않아요. 첫 번째 문제 때문에 일어나요. 이걸 알아내려면 고객이나 잠재 고객(prospective customer)에게 조심스럽게 귀 기울이고, 알아내는 동안 바로 피치(pitch)하려 들지 말아야 해요.
text_zh: 其实人们起床后首先想到的不是第二重要的问题，而是最迫切需要解决的那个问题。所以你得仔细听客户怎么说，在摸清楚这一点的时候千万别急着推销，不管是现有客户还是潜在客户都一样。
text_es: La gente no se levanta de la cama por su segundo problema. Se levanta por el primero. Y tienes que escuchar con mucha atención y no estar vendiendo a tu cliente o prospecto mientras tratas de entender esto.
context: Jeff is explaining why product craft must come after solving a real customer problem. He emphasizes the importance of identifying customers' most urgent, burning problems rather than secondary issues. Jeff is teaching a methodology for customer discovery that focuses on listening rather than pitching, arguing that customers will only be truly motivated to act on their most pressing challenges.
vocabulary_highlights: get out of bed for, carefully listen, not pitch
topics: Customer Development, Product Management, Starting a Company

speaker: Jeff Weinstein
speaker_expertise: B2B SaaS, Product Management, User Experience
text: If you've earned trust along the way, and certainly not pitching is a great way of earning trust. You're just listening. We've learned a lot at Stripe from that. And that's where you can start to find adjacencies, right?
text_ko: 그동안 신뢰를 쌓아왔다면, 확실히 피칭(pitching)을 하지 않는 게 신뢰를 얻는 좋은 방법이에요. 그저 상대 얘기를 들어주는 거죠. 스트라이프에서도 그걸 통해 많은 걸 배웠어요. 바로 그 지점에서 인접 영역(adjacencies)을 찾아보기 시작할 수 있어요, 그렇죠?
text_zh: 如果你在这个过程中赢得了信任，不推销反而是建立信任的好方法。你就是在倾听。我们在Stripe学到了很多这样的经验。这样你就能开始找到相关的机会点，对吧？
text_es: Si has ganado confianza en el proceso, y desde luego no hacer pitch todo el tiempo es una excelente manera de ganar esa confianza. Simplemente escuchas. En Stripe hemos aprendido muchísimo de eso. Y ahí es donde puedes empezar a encontrar oportunidades adyacentes, ¿no?
context: Jeff is continuing his explanation of how to discover customer problems through listening rather than pitching. He's describing how this approach builds trust with customers and can reveal new product opportunities. Jeff explains how at Stripe, they discovered adjacencies - related business opportunities - by listening to customers describe problems that weren't directly related to Stripe's core payment processing business.
vocabulary_highlights: earned trust along the way, not pitching, find adjacencies
topics: Customer Development, Strategy & Planning, Product Management

speaker: Jeffrey Pfeffer
text: Well, it's important because a guy named Gerald Ferris developed a scale of political skill. And he and a bunch of his colleagues over the years did a lot of empirical research that demonstrates that political skill is associated with a lot of positive outcomes, salary, getting promoted, being happy in your career, being happy in your job, being less stressed. So the reason why you should pay attention to this is because it leads to a lot of good things.
text_ko: 중요한 이유가 있어요. 제럴드 페리스(Gerald Ferris)라는 분이 '정치적 기술'(political skill)이라는 척도를 개발했고, 그와 동료들이 수년간 실증 연구를 통해 이 정치적 기술이 연봉, 승진, 경력·직무 만족도, 스트레스 감소 등 여러 긍정적 결과와 연관돼 있다는 걸 보여줬어요. 그래서 관심을 가져야 해요—결국 많은 좋은 일로 이어지니까요.
text_zh: 这个很重要，因为有个叫Gerald Ferris的人开发了一套政治技能量表(political skill scale)。他和同事们这些年做了大量实证研究(empirical research)，证明政治技能跟很多好结果都有关系——涨工资、升职、职业发展顺心、工作开心、压力也小。所以你应该关注这个，因为它能给你带来很多好处。
text_es: Bueno, es importante porque un tipo llamado Gerald Ferris desarrolló una escala de habilidades políticas. Y él junto con varios colegas suyos hicieron durante años un montón de investigación empírica que demuestra que las habilidades políticas están relacionadas con muchos resultados positivos: mejor salario, conseguir ascensos, estar contento en tu carrera profesional, estar a gusto en tu trabajo, tener menos estrés. Así que la razón por la que deberías prestarle atención a esto es porque te lleva a muchas cosas buenas.
context: Lenny asks Jeffrey why it's important for people to learn about power despite it making them uncomfortable. Jeffrey explains that political skill has been scientifically proven to correlate with career success and wellbeing. He references research by Gerald Ferris showing that developing political skills leads to concrete benefits including higher salaries, more promotions, greater job satisfaction, and reduced stress levels.
vocabulary_highlights: empirical research, political skill, positive outcomes

speaker: Jeffrey Pfeffer
text: I think we've confused the tool for how it has been used. I see people with hammers hitting other people on the head. That does not mean that a hammer is not a useful tool. You can take a screwdriver and stab it into somebody's belly. I have a very dear friend who we'll probably talk about later in the podcast. Laura Esserman is a breast cancer surgeon, and I tell people, Laura has a knife. She uses it to cure cancer.
text_ko: 저는 우리가 도구 자체와 그 도구가 실제로 어떻게 쓰였는지를 혼동하고 있는 것 같아요. 망치를 들고 다른 사람 머리를 때리는 사람들을 보곤 해요. 그렇다고 해서 망치가 쓸모없는 도구라는 건 아니에요. 드라이버로 누군가의 배를 찌를 수도 있죠. 제가 아주 친한 친구가 한 분 있는데, 팟캐스트(podcast)에서 나중에 아마 얘기할 거예요. 로라 에서먼(Laura Esserman)은 유방암 외과의사(breast cancer surgeon)이에요. 저는 사람들에게 '로라에겐 칼이 있다'고 말하곤 해요. 그녀는 그 칼로 암을 치료해요.
text_zh: 我觉得我们把工具本身和它的使用方式给搞混了。就好比我看到有人拿锤子砸别人脑袋，但这不代表锤子本身不是个有用的工具啊。你也可以拿螺丝刀捅别人肚子，对吧？我有个特别好的朋友，我们待会儿在播客里可能会聊到她。Laura Esserman是个乳腺癌外科医生，我跟别人说，Laura手里有把刀，但她是用这把刀来治癌症的。
text_es: Creo que hemos confundido la herramienta con el uso que se le ha dado. Veo gente que agarra un martillo y le pega a otros en la cabeza. Eso no significa que un martillo no sea una herramienta útil. Puedes tomar un destornillador y clavárselo a alguien en el estómago. Tengo una amiga muy querida de la que probablemente hablaremos más tarde en el podcast. Laura Esserman es cirujana de cáncer de mama, y yo le digo a la gente: Laura tiene un bisturí. Lo usa para curar el cáncer.
context: Lenny mentions that power-building techniques feel uncomfortable because they're not how people want to live their lives. Jeffrey responds by explaining that people have developed negative associations with power because they've seen it misused. He uses analogies comparing power to tools like hammers, screwdrivers, and surgical knives - arguing that the tool itself isn't inherently bad, but rather depends on how it's used by the person wielding it.
vocabulary_highlights: confused the tool for, very dear friend

speaker: Jeffrey Pfeffer
text: The class is extremely popular. I have a long waiting list. It's kind of mythical. And because of the principle of social influence, we are influenced by what other people do. We're influenced in our choices of restaurants, we're influenced in our choices of music. I'm not sure I like Taylor Swift, but I certainly want to go see Taylor Swift because everybody else is.
text_ko: 이 수업은 엄청 인기 있어요. 대기자 명단도 길고, 왠지 전설 같은 느낌이에요. 그리고 사회적 영향력(principle of social influence) 때문에 우리는 다른 사람들 하는 대로 영향을 받아요. 식당을 어디로 갈지나 어떤 음악을 들을지도 다들 하는 걸 보고 결정하죠. 저는 테일러 스위프트를 정말 좋아하는지는 잘 모르겠지만, 다들 가니까 저도 꼭 보러 가고 싶어요.
text_zh: 这个课程特别火，我这儿排队等着上课的人一大堆。这课程都成传说了。其实这就是社会影响力的原理，我们会被别人的行为影响。选餐厅的时候我们会看别人去哪儿，听音乐也会跟风。我其实不确定自己是不是真的喜欢泰勒·斯威夫特，但我肯定想去看她的演唱会，因为大家都去看。
text_es: La clase es súper popular. Tengo una lista de espera larguísima. Se ha vuelto como algo mítico. Y por el principio de influencia social, nos dejamos influir por lo que hace la demás gente. Nos influye a la hora de elegir restaurantes, nos influye en la música que escuchamos. No sé si realmente me gusta Taylor Swift, pero desde luego quiero ir a verla porque todo el mundo va.
context: Lenny asks why Jeffrey's class isn't for everyone and why being less judgmental is important. Jeffrey explains that his Stanford course has become extremely popular with long waiting lists, creating a mythical reputation. He discusses the principle of social influence - how people are influenced by what others do in their choices of restaurants, music, and even classes, using Taylor Swift as an example of how popularity itself drives more interest.
vocabulary_highlights: long waiting list, kind of mythical, principle of social influence

speaker: Jeffrey Pfeffer
text: If I decide that Lenny is whatever set of bad adjectives you want to use, dumb, incompetent, immoral, whatever, my ability to build a positive relationship with you, and you remain on my critical path, becomes almost zero unless you're a better actor or I'm a better actor than I think most people are. So therefore, you should suspend judgment in the sense that if somebody is on your critical path, the only judgment you should make is they're on my critical path.
text_ko: 제가 레니(Lenny)를 멍청하고, 무능하고, 비도덕적이라고 결론내린다면—어떤 부정적 형용사든 상관없어요—당신이 제 크리티컬 패스(critical path)에 계속 남아 있는 한 당신과 긍정적인 관계를 쌓을 수 있는 가능성은 거의 없어져요. 당신이 평소 사람들보다 훨씬 더 잘 행동하거나 제가 평소 사람들보다 훨씬 더 잘해야 가능한데, 그걸 기대하기는 어렵죠. 그래서 판단을 보류하는 게 좋아요. 누군가가 당신의 크리티컬 패스에 있다면, 내리는 유일한 판단은 '그 사람이 내 크리티컬 패스에 있구나' 정도면 충분해요.
text_zh: 如果我认定Lenny就是各种不好的词汇，比如笨、没能力、品德有问题什么的，那我跟你建立良好关系的可能性基本为零，除非你我都是超级会演戏的人，但我觉得大部分人都做不到这样。所以你应该暂时不要下判断，如果某个人在你的关键路径(critical path)上，你唯一需要判断的就是——他在我的关键路径上，仅此而已。
text_es: Si decido que Lenny es todo lo malo que se te ocurra—tonto, incompetente, inmoral, lo que sea—mi capacidad de construir una relación positiva contigo, cuando tú sigues siendo clave para mi proyecto, se vuelve prácticamente cero, a menos que tú o yo seamos mejores actores de lo que creo que es la mayoría de la gente. Por eso, debes suspender el juicio en el sentido de que si alguien está en tu ruta crítica (critical path), lo único que debes pensar es "esta persona está en mi ruta crítica" y ya.
context: Jeffrey explains why being judgmental hinders professional effectiveness. He describes how jobs require interdependence and getting things done through other people. When someone is on your 'critical path' (essential to accomplishing your work goals), making negative judgments about them severely damages your ability to build the positive working relationship you need, regardless of personal feelings about that person.
vocabulary_highlights: critical path, suspend judgment, set of bad adjectives

speaker: Jeffrey Pfeffer
text: And Derek Kan was a little bit older when he went through the MBA program. And in 2012, his Doing Power project was to get appointed to be Mitt Romney's, it was Mitt Romney was running for president, to be head of economic policy for the Romney campaign. Believe it or not, he was offered the job. Believe it or not, he turned it down for reasons which we could go into if you want, but aren't that interesting. He wound up relatively soon thereafter as number three in the transportation department, working for Elaine Chao.
text_ko: 데릭 칸은 MBA 프로그램(MBA program)을 다닐 때는 나이가 좀 더 있었어요. 2012년에 그의 Doing Power 프로젝트(Doing Power project)는 밋 롬니가 대선에 출마했을 때 롬니 캠프의 경제정책 책임자(head of economic policy)로 임명되는 것이 목표였어요. 믿기 어렵겠지만 실제로 그 제안을 받았고, 더 놀랍게도 그 제안을 거절했어요. 이유는 원하시면 얘기해드릴 수 있지만 별로 흥미롭진 않아요. 그 뒤 얼마 지나지 않아 그는 교통부(Department of Transportation)에서 3인자 자리에 올라 엘레인 초 밑에서 일하게 되었어요.
text_zh: Derek Kan读MBA的时候年纪稍微大一点。2012年的时候，他的实践项目(Doing Power project)是想去给竞选总统的Mitt Romney当经济政策负责人。你可能不信，人家真的给了他这个机会。你可能更不信的是，他居然拒绝了——原因嘛，要是你想听我可以说说，不过其实也没那么有意思。之后没多久，他就去了交通部，在Elaine Chao手下当三把手。
text_es: Y Derek Kan era un poco mayor cuando hizo el MBA. Y en 2012, su proyecto de Doing Power era conseguir que lo nombraran como jefe de política económica para la campaña de Mitt Romney, que en ese momento se postulaba para presidente. Aunque no lo creas, le ofrecieron el puesto. Aunque no lo creas, lo rechazó por razones que podríamos platicar si quieres, pero que no son tan interesantes. Poco después terminó como número tres en el departamento de transporte, trabajando bajo Elaine Chao.
context: Lenny asks about examples from Jeffrey's homework assignments called 'Doing Power' projects where students practice power-building skills. Jeffrey shares the extreme example of Derek Kan, an MBA student who set a goal to become head of economic policy for Mitt Romney's presidential campaign. Despite being offered the position (which he declined), this experience led to high-level government positions, ultimately running the $6 trillion US budget just six years after business school.
vocabulary_highlights: Doing Power project, believe it or not, wound up

speaker: Jeffrey Pfeffer
text: There are by definition fewer positions at the top than at the bottom. The world, we might not like this, and I know people, the late Tony Hsieh, the Zappos tried to do holacracy or whatever, but the world is essentially hierarchical. The animal kingdom is hierarchical. It is better to be at the top than at the bottom for a number of reasons. Okay. If that is true, if there are fewer positions at the top and then at the bottom, then your job to advance your career is to figure out how to get promoted.
text_ko: 기본적으로 위쪽 자리가 아래쪽보다 적어요. 이걸 좋아하지 않을 수도 있고, 이미 세상을 떠난 토니 셰이 같은 사람들은 Zappos에서 홀라크러시(holacracy) 같은 걸 시도하기도 했죠. 하지만 세상은 본질적으로 위계적(hierarchical)이에요. 동물의 세계도 마찬가지고요. 여러 가지 이유로 위쪽에 있는 게 아래에 있는 것보다 나아요. 그게 사실이라면, 위쪽 자리가 적다는 걸 전제로 당신의 커리어를 진전시키려면 어떻게 승진할지를 알아내는 것이 당신의 일이에요.
text_zh: 很简单的道理，越往上职位越少，越往下职位越多。这个世界就是这样，咱们可能不爱听，我知道有些人，比如已故的托尼·谢（Tony Hsieh），Zappos那家公司试过什么全员制（holacracy）之类的，但这个世界本质上就是有等级的。动物世界也是这样，弱肉强食。在上面肯定比在下面强，这个道理大家都懂。好，既然上面的位子少，下面的位子多，那你想往上爬，就得琢磨怎么升职。
text_es: Por definición hay menos puestos arriba que abajo. Al mundo, puede que no nos guste esto, y conozco gente, como el difunto Tony Hsieh, el de Zappos que intentó hacer holacracia o como se llame, but el mundo es esencialmente jerárquico. El reino animal es jerárquico. Es mejor estar arriba que abajo por varias razones. Bueno. Si eso es cierto, si hay menos puestos arriba que abajo, entonces tu trabajo para hacer crecer tu carrera es descifrar cómo conseguir un ascenso.
context: Lenny asks Jeffrey to explain the power of building a personal brand, which makes people uncomfortable. Jeffrey begins by explaining the fundamental reality of organizational hierarchies - there are fewer positions at the top than at the bottom, making competition inevitable. He acknowledges that while some have tried alternatives like holacracy, hierarchical structures remain dominant in both human organizations and nature, making career advancement necessarily competitive.
vocabulary_highlights: by definition, essentially hierarchical, for a number of reasons

speaker: Jen Abel
text: In the very early days, people will discount till the cows come home because they think that's the way to get a deal done. The best clients are not going to do that to you. If they're sitting there nickel-and-diming you, they're not fully bought in on what you're selling them.
text_ko: 초기에는 많은 사람이 거래를 성사시키려고 끝없이 할인을 해요(discount till the cows come home). 그게 딜을 성사시키는 방법이라고 생각하니까요. 하지만 최고의 고객들은 그렇게 하지 않아요. 만약 고객이 계속 꼬투리 잡아 한 푼씩 깎으려 한다면(nickel-and-diming), 그건 당신이 제안하는 것에 완전히 공감하고 투자한 상태가 아니라고 볼 수 있어요(fully bought in).
text_zh: 刚开始做生意的时候，很多人会拼命砍价，觉得这样才能成交。但真正的好客户不会这么折腾你。如果他们老是跟你斤斤计较，抠这个抠那个的，说明他们根本就没真心想买你的东西。
text_es: En los primeros días, la gente va a regatear hasta el cansancio porque creen que así es como se cierra un trato. Los mejores clientes no te van a hacer eso. Si están ahí regateándote cada centavo, es porque no están realmente convencidos de lo que les estás vendiendo.
context: Lenny mentions that most founders would rather get 10 ten-thousand-dollar deals than lose nine and get one hundred-thousand-dollar deal. Jen explains why this approach is problematic for enterprise sales. She argues that discounting heavily signals weakness and attracts the wrong type of clients who aren't truly committed to the product's value.
vocabulary_highlights: discount till the cows come home, nickel-and-diming, fully bought in

speaker: Jen Abel
text: As soon as you become a comparison, as soon as you become one of three that they're testing out, you've already sort of lost. It's all about differentiation. Here's what you will be able to do tomorrow because of how we're going to serve you today.
text_ko: 비교 대상이 되거나 그들이 시험해보는 세 후보 중 하나로 여겨지는 순간, 이미 어느 정도 불리해요. 핵심은 차별화(differentiation)이에요. 오늘 우리가 어떻게 서비스를 제공하느냐에 따라 내일 무엇을 할 수 있게 될지가 결정돼요. 그래서 우리가 오늘 이렇게 해드리면, 내일은 이렇게 하실 수 있어요.
text_zh: 一旦你变成了被比较的对象，一旦你成了他们要测试的三个选择之一，基本上就已经输了。关键在于差异化(differentiation)。要让客户知道：因为我们今天为你提供的服务，明天你就能做到这些事情。
text_es: En cuanto te conviertes en una opción más para comparar, en cuanto te vuelves uno de los tres que están evaluando, ya prácticamente perdiste. Todo se trata de diferenciación. Esto es lo que vas a poder lograr mañana gracias a cómo te vamos a atender hoy.
context: Jen is explaining how to position your product in enterprise sales. She emphasizes that once a potential client starts comparing your solution to others in a competitive evaluation process, you've lost your advantage. The key is to differentiate yourself by focusing on future opportunities and outcomes rather than competing on features or price.
vocabulary_highlights: sort of lost, testing out

speaker: Jen Abel
text: Enterprise is the number one thing they buy services, they know how to do it's super easy, they do it all of the time. It's like the most consistent thing they do. It's their largest budget item, external resources, consultants, whatever.
text_ko: 기업(enterprise)은 서비스 구매가 가장 큰 비중이에요. 어떻게 하는지 잘 알고 있어서 아주 손쉽게 처리해요. 늘 하던 일이니까요. 가장 일관되게 하는 활동이고, 예산도 가장 큰 항목이에요. 외부 리소스(external resources)나 컨설턴트(consultants) 같은 데에 많이 쓰여요.
text_zh: 大企业买服务这事儿是他们的强项，轻车熟路的，天天都在做。这是他们最稳定的操作了，也是预算里最大的一块 - 外部资源啊、咨询啊什么的。
text_es: Las empresas grandes son las que más compran servicios, ya saben cómo hacerlo y es súper fácil para ellas, lo hacen todo el tiempo. Es como lo más constante que hacen. Es su partida presupuestaria más grande: recursos externos, consultores, lo que sea.
context: Lenny asks about Jen's advice to start with services rather than just selling software products to enterprises. Jen explains that large companies are very comfortable buying services and consulting - it's something they do regularly and have large budgets for. This makes services an easier entry point than trying to sell new technology solutions.
vocabulary_highlights: external resources, budget item

speaker: Jen Abel
text: It's more of an art. It's all about deal crafting. It is a relationship you're building with someone. If they know they can call on you, people will turn over rocks for you. I have a client at a Fortune 10 company where I was like, 'It's so important we get the deal done this year. Is that possible?' And she's like, 'It's a tall order, but if it's going to help you, let's do it.' These are how enterprise deals gets done. It's relationships.
text_ko: 이건 더 예술에 가까워요. 결국은 딜 구성(deal crafting)이 핵심이에요. 누군가와 쌓아가는 관계예요. 상대가 필요할 때 도움을 요청해도 된다고 알면, 사람들은 발품까지 팔아가며 도와줘요. 포춘 10대 기업(Fortune 10 company)의 고객이 한 분 있는데 제가 “올해 이 딜을 꼭 마무리하는 게 중요해요. 가능할까요?”라고 물었더니 그분이 “무리한 요청이긴 하지만, 당신에게 도움이 된다면 해보죠”라고 하더라고요. 엔터프라이즈 딜(enterprise deals)은 이렇게 관계로 성사돼요. 결국 관계예요.
text_zh: 这更像是一门艺术。关键在于怎么做交易(deal crafting)。你其实是在跟人建立关系。如果他们知道有事能找你，别人就会为你想方设法。我有个客户在世界500强前10的公司，我跟她说："今年把这单搞定对我们特别重要，有可能吗？"她就说："要求是挺高的，但如果能帮到你，那咱们就干吧。"企业级交易(enterprise deals)就是这么成的，靠的就是关系。
text_es: Es más un arte, ¿sabes? Todo se trata de construir el negocio (deal crafting). Lo que estás haciendo es crear una relación con alguien. Si saben que pueden contar contigo, la gente va a mover cielo y tierra por ti. Tengo una cliente en una empresa Fortune 10 donde le dije, 'Es súper importante que cerremos este negocio este año. ¿Será posible?' Y me dice, 'Está complicado, pero si te va a ayudar, hagámoslo.' Así es como se cierran los negocios grandes (enterprise deals). Todo son relaciones.
context: Lenny mentions that Jen talks about enterprise sales being very creative. Jen responds by explaining that enterprise sales is more of an art than a science, requiring creativity in structuring deals and building deep relationships. She shares a real example of how a strong relationship with a Fortune 10 client led them to expedite a deal specifically to help her, demonstrating the power of relationship-based selling.
vocabulary_highlights: deal crafting, turn over rocks for you, tall order

speaker: Jen Abel
text: I want to email someone not in the database that's getting hit by a million folks. I want to take a back door in, not the front door where everyone else is trick or treating.
text_ko: 데이터베이스(database)가 이미 수많은 사람들에게 시달리고 있어서, 그 안에 없는 사람에게 이메일을 보내고 싶어요. 다들 우르르 몰려가는 앞문(front door)으로 가지 않고 백도어(back door)로 슬쩍 들어가고 싶어요.
text_zh: 我想给数据库里没有的人发邮件，不想走那些被无数人轰炸的渠道。我要走后门，不走正门——正门那儿人太多了，跟要糖的小孩似的排着队呢。
text_es: Quiero contactar por email a alguien que no está en la base de datos pero que está siendo bombardeado por un millón de personas. Quiero entrar por la puerta de atrás, no por la puerta principal donde todos están pidiendo dulces.
context: Lenny asks about the state of the art in go-to-market outbound tooling. Jen explains why she doesn't use automated tools for prospecting. She believes that AI tools and databases are creating too much noise because they all target the same people. Instead, she prefers finding unique ways to reach prospects that others aren't using.
vocabulary_highlights: back door in, front door, trick or treating

speaker: Jen Abel
text: The market doesn't want to be sold to, they want to buy. And I know that it's very hard to hire a really good enterprise salesperson. The number of people that I've interviewed, I can count on my hand the ones that I get really, really excited by.
text_ko: 시장은 누군가에게 일방적으로 팔리기를 원하지 않고, 스스로 사기를 원해요. 그리고 진짜 좋은 엔터프라이즈 영업 담당자(enterprise salesperson)를 뽑는 건 정말 어렵다는 걸 잘 알아요. 제가 면접 본 사람들 중에서 정말로 기대가 되고 가슴이 뛰었던 사람은 손에 꼽을 정도예요.
text_zh: 市场不想被推销，他们想要主动购买。我知道招到一个真正优秀的企业销售特别难。我面试过那么多人，真正让我眼前一亮的，用一只手都能数得过来。
text_es: El mercado no quiere que le vendan, quiere comprar. Y sé que es súper difícil contratar a un vendedor empresarial realmente bueno. De toda la gente que he entrevistado, puedo contar con los dedos de una mano a los que realmente me emocionan.
context: Jen is discussing what makes a good enterprise salesperson and why it's challenging to find the right people. She explains that taking typical salespeople and putting them in startup sales roles often fails because it feels too 'salesy' to prospects. She emphasizes that great enterprise salespeople are as rare as great founders or engineers.
vocabulary_highlights: count on my hand, get really, really excited by

speaker: Jen Abel
text: So if you can focus the messaging in a way that speaks to something that has a bit of shock value or is counterintuitive, you'll get them to continue reading. So first and foremost is relevancy.
text_ko: 따라서 메시지(messaging)를 충격 요소(shock value)가 있거나 직관에 반하는(counterintuitive) 방향으로 맞춰 전달하면 사람들이 계속 읽게 만들 수 있어요. 그래서 무엇보다도 가장 중요한 건 관련성(relevancy)이에요.
text_zh: 所以如果你能把信息包装得有点震撼性或者反常理的感觉，就能抓住他们继续看下去。说到底，最重要的还是相关性。
text_es: Entonces, si puedes enfocar el mensaje de una manera que hable de algo que tenga cierto impacto o que vaya contra lo que esperan, vas a lograr que sigan leyendo. Así que lo más importante es la relevancia.
context: Lenny asks Jen how founders can get prospects to pay attention when so many SaaS tools are constantly emailing potential customers. Jen explains that founders need to cut through the noise by crafting messages that stand out. She emphasizes that relevancy is more important than personalization, and founders should lead with something that has shock value or is counterintuitive to make prospects pause and want to learn more.
vocabulary_highlights: shock value, counterintuitive

speaker: Jen Abel
text: You need to be vulnerable. I would be very open and honest with where you are. Hey, I'm an early stage startup. We have a lot to learn. Can we kind of gain your insight into how this problem is manifesting on your side? Founder led sales is not about revenue on day one. It is about learning as fast as humanly possible to get to that pulse, so that you can earn the right to sell.
text_ko: 너무 솔직해지는 게 중요해요. 지금 내가 어떤 상황인지에 대해 개방적이고 정직하게 이야기하는 게 좋겠어요. 저희는 초기 스타트업이고, 배울 게 정말 많아요. 이 문제를 당신 쪽에서 어떻게 겪고 있는지에 대한 통찰을 얻을 수 있을까요? 창업자가 이끄는 세일즈는 첫날부터 수익을 내는 게 아니에요. 가능한 한 빨리 배우는 게 중요하고, 그 과정을 통해 고객의 니즈를 파악해야 나중에 판매할 수 있는 자격을 얻는 거예요.
text_zh: 你得放下身段，坦诚一点。我会很开放很真诚地说出现在的情况。就直接说，嘿，我们是个早期创业公司，还有很多要学的。能不能跟我们分享一下，这个问题在你们那边是怎么表现的？创始人亲自做销售，第一天不是为了收入，而是要尽快学习，摸到市场的脉搏，这样才能赢得销售的资格。
text_es: Tienes que ser vulnerable. Yo sería súper abierto y honesto sobre dónde estás parado. Oye, somos una startup en etapa temprana. Tenemos mucho que aprender. ¿Podríamos conocer tu perspectiva sobre cómo se está manifestando este problema de tu lado? Las ventas lideradas por el fundador (founder led sales) no se tratan de generar ingresos desde el primer día. Se trata de aprender lo más rápido humanamente posible para captar esa esencia, para que puedas ganarte el derecho a vender.
context: Lenny asks what founders should do once they're on a phone call with a prospect to get them to engage further. Jen explains that founders should be vulnerable about being early-stage rather than pretending to have a fully-built product. This honesty gets better feedback because prospects are more willing to give candid input when they know they can influence the product before it's finalized. The goal at this stage is learning, not immediate revenue.
vocabulary_highlights: gain your insight, manifesting on your side, get to that pulse, earn the right to sell

speaker: Jen Abel
text: When they start getting their gears churning in their head about, and this is the beauty about not having a product and not showing them anything, they're visualizing in their head now. This is a really powerful thing, which is like, so tell me how this looks in your head?
text_ko: 사람들이 머릿속에서 생각이 막 굴러가기 시작할 때요. 제품이 없고 아무것도 보여주지 않는 것의 묘미가 바로 그거예요 — 지금 스스로 머릿속으로 상상하고 있다는 거죠. 이건 정말 강력한 일이에요. 그러니까, 머릿속에는 어떻게 보이나요?
text_zh: 当他们开始在脑子里转悠这些想法的时候，这就是不展示产品、什么都不给他们看的妙处——他们现在完全是在脑子里想象画面。这招特别厉害，你就问他们：跟我说说，你脑子里想的是什么样子？
text_es: Cuando empiezan a darle vueltas en la cabeza y aquí está lo bueno de no tener un producto y no enseñarles nada, porque ahora se están imaginando todo mentalmente. Esto es súper poderoso, entonces les preguntas: "oye, cuéntame cómo te lo imaginas tú"
context: Jen is explaining how to identify if there's real interest during sales conversations. She advises founders to avoid showing demos too early and instead get prospects talking about the problem. When prospects start visualizing solutions in their minds without seeing a product, it's a powerful signal of genuine interest. Founders should ask prospects to describe what they're imagining to gather valuable insights.
vocabulary_highlights: getting their gears churning, visualizing in their head

speaker: Jen Abel
text: With that, you can literally turn a customer into a guide by asking them to co-author the scope. The scope of work. The co-authorship piece is important for two reasons. It helps you understand where they're on their biomaturity.
text_ko: 이렇게 하면 고객에게 작업 범위(scope of work)를 공동 저작(co-author)하도록 요청해서, 말 그대로 고객을 가이드로 만들 수 있어요. 공동 저작(co-authorship)은 두 가지 이유로 중요해요. 그중 하나는 그들이 바이오성숙도(biomaturity)의 어느 단계에 있는지 파악하는 데 도움이 되기 때문이에요.
text_zh: 这样一来，你就可以让客户当你的向导，让他们跟你一起来定项目范围。工作范围嘛。这个共同制定很重要，有两个原因。一个是能帮你了解他们现在处在什么发展阶段。
text_es: Con eso, literalmente puedes convertir a un cliente en tu guía pidiéndole que colabore contigo en definir el alcance del proyecto. Esa parte de trabajar juntos en el documento es clave por dos razones. Te ayuda a entender en qué punto están con su madurez biológica (biomaturity).
context: Jen explains how to make prospects feel invested in the solution during later sales conversations. By asking prospects to co-author the scope of work, founders can assess the prospect's buying maturity - whether they have existing processes and strategies to solve the problem. If they lack these foundations, they may need to buy services first before purchasing technology, which is common for 40-50% of B2B SaaS companies according to Jen's experience.
vocabulary_highlights: turn a customer into a guide, co-author the scope, biomaturity

speaker: Jen Abel
text: If you don't, it's so easy for it to just go there and die. Another piece that's important with procurement is explaining exactly what you do and don't do. Because if you say you do a bunch of things and they can't really place you, they're going to send you to the kitchen sink of contracting an MSA.
text_ko: 그걸 안 하면 그냥 거기서 묻혀 버리기 쉬워요. 조달 쪽에서 또 중요한 한 가지는 우리가 정확히 뭘 하고 뭘 안 하는지 분명히 설명하는 거예요. 여러 가지를 다 한다고 해놓고 상대가 우리를 어떤 카테고리에 넣어야 할지 모르면 결국엔 모든 걸 다 끼워넣는 식으로 마스터 서비스 계약(Master Service Agreement, MSA)으로 몰아버리려고 해요.
text_zh: 如果你不这样做的话，很容易就石沉大海了。采购这块还有个重要的点，就是要把你做什么、不做什么说得特别清楚。因为如果你说你什么都能做，他们又搞不清楚你到底是干嘛的，那就会把你扔到那种什么都管的万能合同(MSA)里去。
text_es: Si no lo haces, es súper fácil que todo se vaya al traste y muera ahí mismo. Otra cosa clave con las compras es explicar exactamente qué haces y qué no haces. Porque si dices que haces un montón de cosas y no te pueden ubicar bien, te van a mandar al cajón de sastre de contratos con un MSA.
context: Jen is explaining how to navigate the procurement process in enterprise sales. She advises founders to do most of the paperwork themselves to make the procurement team's job easier, since startups are often small deals that can get sidelined. She warns that if procurement can't easily classify what a startup does, they'll default to high-risk contracting requirements that can kill deals.
vocabulary_highlights: go there and die, kitchen sink of contracting, place you

speaker: Jen Abel
text: It's qualification. Qualification because if you spend your time on the wrong leads, that equates to a zero. So if you don't get that first level right, let me put it this way, everyone that I know says they have a bottom of funnel problem. It's never a bottom of funnel problem. It's a top of funnel problem.
text_ko: 핵심은 적격성 판단(qualification)이에요. 잘못된 리드(leads)에 시간을 쓰면 결과는 제로예요. 그래서 그 첫 단계(첫 레벨)를 제대로 못 잡으면, 이렇게 말할게요: 제가 아는 사람들은 다들 '퍼널 하단(bottom of funnel) 문제'라고 하는데, 사실 그건 절대 그런 문제가 아니에요. 늘 퍼널 상단(top of funnel) 문제예요.
text_zh: 关键是要筛选客户。为什么这么说呢？如果你把时间浪费在不靠谱的潜在客户(leads)身上，那就等于白忙活。所以如果你第一步就没做对，我这么跟你说吧，我认识的人都说他们漏斗底部(bottom of funnel)有问题。其实根本不是底部的问题，而是漏斗顶部(top of funnel)出了问题。
text_es: Es puro tema de calificación. Calificación porque si te gastas el tiempo con los leads equivocados, eso se traduce en cero resultados. Entonces, si no haces bien ese primer nivel, te lo pongo así: todo el mundo que conozco dice que tiene un problema en la parte baja del embudo (bottom of funnel). Nunca es un problema de abajo del embudo. Es un problema de arriba del embudo (top of funnel).
context: Lenny asks Jen where founders most commonly get stuck in the sales process and where there's the biggest opportunity to improve conversion. Jen explains that the biggest issue is qualification - talking to the wrong prospects or using the wrong messaging. She notes that founders often think they have closing problems when they actually have qualification problems at the top of their sales funnel.
vocabulary_highlights: equates to a zero, bottom of funnel problem, top of funnel problem

speaker: Jeremy Henrickson
speaker_expertise: Product Strategy, Growth Strategy, User Experience
text: When in fact where you really learn where the challenges are or the problems or the successes is by just being there with the people in the trenches on one of the things, whichever one seems hardest or most complicated. And so I try to do that as often as I can, and I found that I always learn a lot by going through that detailed exercise.
text_ko: 사실 진짜로 어디에 도전 과제나 문제가 있고, 또 어디서 성공이 일어나는지는 가장 어렵거나 복잡해 보이는 일 하나에 대해 실무자들과 함께 현장에 직접 있어 봐야 알게 돼요. 그래서 저는 가능한 한 자주 그렇게 하려고 하고, 그 세부적인 과정을 겪어 보면 항상 많은 걸 배우게 되더라고요.
text_zh: 其实真正了解挑战在哪里、问题在哪里、成功在哪里，就得跟一线的人待在一起，特别是那些最难搞、最复杂的事情。所以我尽量多这样做，我发现每次深入了解这些细节，都能学到很多东西。
text_es: La realidad es que donde verdaderamente aprendes cuáles son los retos, los problemas o los éxitos es simplemente estando ahí con la gente que está en primera línea trabajando en los temas más difíciles o complicados. Entonces trato de hacer esto lo más seguido que puedo, y he descubierto que siempre aprendo muchísimo cuando me meto de lleno en esos detalles.
context: Jeremy is explaining his leadership philosophy and approach to maintaining velocity at scale. He discusses the importance of leaders not just delegating from above but actually engaging directly with the detailed work. Jeremy emphasizes that rather than just floating above and directing teams from a distance, effective leaders must dive deep into the most challenging problems alongside their teams to truly understand what's happening and learn from the process.
vocabulary_highlights: in the trenches, detailed exercise

speaker: Jeremy Henrickson
speaker_expertise: Product Strategy, Growth Strategy, User Experience
text: I think the biggest challenge was that in crypto there's just so much uncertainty in general, simple questions like, is Ethereum going to be a thing, are the subject of debate. And no one actually at the time had an answer to that question. Lots of really strong opinions and so you have to be able to have those debates because lots is going on, but then you have to be able to come out of those conversations with a clear kind of company point of view that you're all shooting toward.
text_ko: 제일 큰 난제는 크립토(crypto) 분야가 전반적으로 불확실성이 너무 컸다는 거였어요. 이더리움(Ethereum)이 과연 자리잡을지 같은 간단한 질문조차 논쟁거리였죠. 그때는 사실 아무도 그 질문에 대한 답을 갖고 있지 않았고요. 의견들이 워낙 강해서 그런 논쟁을 할 줄 알아야 했고, 일이 많이 벌어지니 그럴 수밖에 없었어요. 하지만 그런 대화들에서 결국 모두가 향할 수 있는 분명한 회사 입장을 정리해 내야 해요.
text_zh: 我觉得最大的挑战就是，加密货币这个领域不确定性太强了，连"以太坊(Ethereum)到底能不能成"这种基本问题都还在争论。当时真的没人能给出确定答案。大家都有自己的强烈观点，所以你必须能够参与这些辩论，因为变化太快了，但同时你又得能从这些讨论中梳理出一个清晰的公司立场，让大家朝着同一个方向努力。
text_es: Creo que el mayor desafío fue que en las criptomonedas hay muchísima incertidumbre en general, preguntas súper básicas como si Ethereum va a funcionar o no, son tema de debate. Y nadie en ese momento tenía una respuesta clara a esa pregunta. Había un montón de opiniones muy fuertes, entonces tienes que poder tener esos debates porque están pasando muchas cosas, pero después tienes que lograr salir de esas conversaciones con una visión clara de la empresa hacia la que todos están apuntando.
context: Lenny asks Jeremy about the biggest challenges of keeping a team focused during Coinbase's period of explosive growth. Jeremy explains the unique difficulties of working in the crypto industry during its volatile early days. He describes how fundamental questions about the future of cryptocurrencies like Ethereum were completely uncertain, yet teams still needed to make decisive product decisions and maintain alignment despite this ambiguity.
vocabulary_highlights: subject of debate, shooting toward

speaker: Jeremy Henrickson
speaker_expertise: Product Strategy, Growth Strategy, User Experience
text: I think there's kind of a universal truth that you want small teams with clear missions. Right? If there's 300 people trying to work on one thing, the just sheer communication challenges, Dunbar's number, all of those things come into play and it's really, really hard to act quickly. And so having smaller groups of people breaking down what is always a very, very large problem into sufficiently small bits that small groups can attack wholeheartedly and minimize horizontal communication, I think is the first thing.
text_ko: 작은 팀에 명확한 미션을 주는 게 보편적인 진리인 것 같아요. 예를 들어 한 가지 일에 300명이 달라붙으면 순수한 의사소통 문제, 던바 수(Dunbar's number) 같은 요소들이 다 작용해서 빠르게 움직이기가 정말 어렵거든요. 그래서 언제나 아주 큰 문제를 소규모 팀이 온전히 몰입해서 해결할 수 있을 만큼 충분히 작은 단위로 쪼개고, 수평적 소통(horizontal communication)을 최소화하는 게 첫 번째라고 생각해요.
text_zh: 我觉得有个普遍的道理，就是你得要小团队，目标还得明确。对吧？如果300个人都在搞同一件事，光是沟通就够你受的，什么邓巴数字(Dunbar's number)这些问题全都冒出来了，想要快速行动根本不可能。所以呢，让小团队把那些超级复杂的大问题拆解成小块，让每个小组都能全力以赴地去攻克，尽量减少横向沟通，我觉得这是最关键的。
text_es: Creo que hay como una verdad universal y es que necesitas equipos pequeños con misiones claras. ¿No? Si tienes 300 personas tratando de trabajar en una sola cosa, nada más los desafíos de comunicación, el número de Dunbar (Dunbar's number), todas esas cosas entran en juego y se vuelve súper, súper difícil actuar rápido. Entonces, tener grupos más pequeños de gente que dividan lo que siempre es un problema gigantesco en pedacitos lo suficientemente pequeños para que equipos chicos puedan atacarlos con todo y minimizar la comunicación horizontal, creo que eso es lo primero.
context: Lenny asks Jeremy about maintaining velocity at scale, which is advice people frequently seek from Jeremy. Jeremy outlines his framework for keeping teams productive as companies grow. He explains that one of the universal principles is organizing work around small, focused teams rather than large groups, referencing concepts like Dunbar's number to explain why large groups struggle with coordination and decision-making speed.
vocabulary_highlights: universal truth, sheer communication challenges, Dunbar's number, attack wholeheartedly, horizontal communication

speaker: Jeremy Henrickson
speaker_expertise: Product Strategy, Growth Strategy, User Experience
text: And in that set of optimizations, you are minimizing the deeper product thinking about what can fully differentiate our product based on not only existing kind of capabilities within our products and platform, but based on what it ought to do in the future. And so it sort of limits product creativity, but worse, it leads to building the wrong thing technically, right?
text_ko: 그런 최적화 과정(optimizations)에만 매몰되면 제품을 진짜로 차별화할 수 있는 부분에 대한 깊은 고민을 줄여 버려요. 제품·플랫폼(platform) 내 기존 기능들(capabilities)만 기준으로 삼고 앞으로 제품이 어떻게 돼야 하는지까지 생각하지 않게 되거든요. 그래서 제품 창의성(product creativity)이 제한되고, 더 나쁜 건 기술적으로(technically) 잘못된 것을 만들게 된다는 거예요.
text_zh: 在这种优化思路下，你其实是在弱化更深层的产品思考——就是我们的产品到底应该怎么做才能真正有差异化，不光是基于现有的产品功能和平台能力，更要考虑未来应该往哪个方向发展。这样一来呢，不仅限制了产品的创新思维，更糟糕的是，在技术层面可能会做出完全错误的东西，对吧？
text_es: Y con ese enfoque de optimizaciones, terminas minimizando el pensamiento más profundo sobre el producto - o sea, qué es lo que realmente puede diferenciar nuestro producto, no solo basándose en las capacidades que ya tenemos en nuestros productos y plataforma, sino en lo que debería hacer a futuro. Entonces como que limita la creatividad del producto, pero peor aún, te lleva a construir la cosa equivocada técnicamente, ¿no?
context: Lenny asks Jeremy about his philosophy on MVPs (minimum viable products), as he's heard Jeremy is not a big fan of them. Jeremy explains why he believes MVPs can be counterproductive, particularly for companies like Rippling. He argues that when you optimize purely for speed with an MVP approach, you sacrifice the deeper strategic thinking about product differentiation and future scalability, which can lead to fundamental technical architecture mistakes.
vocabulary_highlights: set of optimizations, fully differentiate, sort of limits, leads to building the wrong thing

speaker: Jeremy Henrickson
speaker_expertise: Product Strategy, Growth Strategy, User Experience
text: The idea of a compound startup for us is that we're basically a lot of businesses that all work together. If you think about the products we offer, we have payroll, well, there's entire companies built just on payroll, insurance, and benefits, entire companies. That's our entire life cycle of a whole company.
text_ko: '컴파운드 스타트업(compound startup)'이라는 개념은, 저희 입장에선 기본적으로 서로 함께 작동하는 여러 사업들이 모여 있는 형태예요. 우리가 제공하는 상품을 보면 급여(payroll), 보험(insurance), 복리후생(benefits) 같은 것들이 있고, 사실 급여만으로도 하나의 회사가 될 정도로 독립된 비즈니스가 있어요. 그런 것들이 모여서 한 회사의 전체 라이프사이클(life cycle)을 아우르는 셈이에요.
text_zh: 我们这种复合型初创公司(compound startup)的概念就是，我们其实是把很多业务都整合在一起了。你想想我们提供的产品，有工资发放、保险、福利这些，光是工资发放这一块，就有专门的公司在做，保险和福利也是，都有整个公司专门搞这个。我们这等于是覆盖了一个公司的整个生命周期。
text_es: Para nosotros, la idea de una startup compuesta es que somos básicamente un montón de negocios que trabajan todos juntos. Si te pones a pensar en los productos que ofrecemos, tenemos nóminas, bueno, hay empresas enteras que se dedican solo a nóminas, seguros y beneficios, empresas completas. Eso es todo nuestro ciclo de vida de una empresa entera.
context: Lenny asks Jeremy to explain Rippling's concept of being a 'compound startup' and how this approach impacts their product development and team organization. Jeremy describes how Rippling operates multiple distinct business lines that could each be standalone companies - like payroll, benefits, insurance, and IT management - but they're all built on a unified platform. He's explaining the strategic vision behind building multiple interconnected products rather than focusing on just one vertical.
vocabulary_highlights: compound startup, entire life cycle

speaker: Jeremy Henrickson
speaker_expertise: Product Strategy, Growth Strategy, User Experience
text: I would say it's fundamental, speed of execution. I think in speed of decision-making. It's the thing that is probably the hardest to explain to people before they're here. It's hard to understand until you experience it. It's like let's not schedule a meeting for next week or tomorrow or later today. We're in the middle of a meeting, we need to make a decision.
text_ko: 제일 근본적인 건 실행 속도(speed of execution)예요. 특히 의사결정 속도(speed of decision-making)이요. 여기 오기 전엔 사람들에게 설명하기가 아마 제일 힘들어요. 직접 겪어보기 전엔 잘 와닿지 않거든요. 예를 들면 '다음 주에 하자' '내일 하자' '오늘 늦게 하자'처럼 회의를 미루지 않아요. 회의 도중이라도 결정을 내려야 하면 바로 결정을 내리는 문화예요.
text_zh: 我觉得最根本的就是执行速度，还有决策速度。这个东西可能是最难跟外面的人解释清楚的，不亲身经历真的很难理解。就是那种，别什么下周开会、明天开会，甚至今天晚点开会，我们现在就在开会，现在就得把这事儿定下来。
text_es: Yo diría que es fundamental, la velocidad de ejecución. Me refiero a la velocidad para tomar decisiones. Es lo que probablemente más cuesta explicarle a la gente antes de que llegue aquí. Es difícil de entender hasta que no lo vives. Es como... no vamos a programar una reunión para la próxima semana o para mañana o para más tarde. Estamos en plena reunión, tenemos que decidir ya.
context: Lenny asks Jeremy about unique aspects of Rippling's culture that he hasn't mentioned yet. Jeremy identifies their exceptionally fast pace of execution and decision-making as the most distinctive cultural element. He explains that this speed is so extreme that it's difficult for outsiders to comprehend - instead of scheduling meetings to make decisions, they make decisions immediately within ongoing conversations, even if it means pulling in additional people on the spot.
vocabulary_highlights: fundamental, speed of execution, hardest to explain

speaker: Jeremy Henrickson
speaker_expertise: Product Strategy, Growth Strategy, User Experience
text: In product, you don't own little feature, you own your product and you're expected to be the world's foremost expert in it. And if you are, what that means is instead of having to come back to people three days later with an answer, just off the top of your head, you can be like, 'Yes, this is what I think I should do about that or give me 30 minutes, look something up and I can tell you what we need to do about that.'
text_ko: 제품(product) 업무에서는 작은 기능(feature) 하나만 맡는 게 아니라 제품 전체를 책임져야 하고, 그 제품에 대해서는 세상에서 가장 잘 아는 사람이 돼야 한다고 기대받아요. 그리고 실제로 그렇게 된다면 사람들한테 답을 들고 3일 뒤에 다시 오지 않아도 돼요. 바로 머릿속에서 떠오르는 대로 "응, 이건 이렇게 해야 할 것 같아"라고 말할 수도 있고, "30분만 줘, 찾아보고 우리가 뭘 해야 할지 알려줄게"라고 바로 답할 수 있어요.
text_zh: 做产品的话，你不是只负责某个小功能，而是要对整个产品负责，而且得成为这个领域的绝对专家。如果你真的做到了，那就意味着别人问你问题的时候，你不用过三天才给答复，而是可以马上说："嗯，我觉得应该这么处理"，或者"给我半小时查一下资料，我就能告诉你该怎么办。"
text_es: En producto, no eres dueño de una funcionalidad específica, sino de todo tu producto y se espera que seas el mayor experto del mundo en él. Y si lo eres, eso significa que en lugar de tener que volver con la gente tres días después con una respuesta, así de inmediato, puedes decir: "Sí, esto es lo que creo que deberíamos hacer al respecto" o "dame 30 minutos para revisar algo y te digo qué tenemos que hacer con eso."
context: Jeremy is explaining how Rippling creates a culture of fast decision-making. He describes their expectation that product managers must become deep domain experts in their areas rather than just managing small features. This deep expertise enables them to make quick decisions without lengthy research periods. Jeremy is outlining how this preparation and knowledge depth directly enables their culture of rapid execution and immediate decision-making.
vocabulary_highlights: world's foremost expert, off the top of your head

speaker: Jerry Colonna
speaker_expertise: Executive Coaching, Leadership Development, Company Building
text: The question that I often ask is how have I been complicit in creating the conditions I say I don't want. The purpose of this question is actually to evoke your own agency, is to look at the ways in which you may have been diluting yourself. A perfect example of that would be, I say I don't want to feel busy all the time, but the truth of the matter is I feel really unnerved and disconcerted if my agenda isn't jam-packed.
text_ko: 제가 자주 스스로에게 묻는 질문은 '내가 원하지 않는 상황을 만드는 데 내가 어떻게 일조했을까?'예요. 이 질문의 목적은 사실 당신의 주도성(agency)을 불러일으켜, 스스로를 약화시키는 방식(diluting yourself)을 들여다보게 하는 거예요. 아주 좋은 예로는, 저도 '항상 바쁘게 느끼고 싶지 않다'고 말하지만, 사실 일정이 꽉 차 있지 않으면 불안하고 초조해요.
text_zh: 我经常问自己一个问题：我是怎么参与创造了这些我嘴上说不想要的情况？问这个问题的目的其实是为了唤醒你的主观能动性，让你看看自己在哪些方面可能在削弱自己。一个很好的例子就是，我嘴上说不想总是感觉很忙，但实际上如果我的日程安排不是满满当当的，我反而会觉得心里没底，很不踏实。
text_es: La pregunta que siempre me hago es: ¿en qué he contribuido yo mismo a crear las situaciones que digo que no quiero? El objetivo de esta pregunta es justamente despertar tu capacidad de acción, es ver de qué maneras te has estado saboteando a ti mismo. Un ejemplo perfecto sería: digo que no quiero sentirme ocupado todo el tiempo, pero la realidad es que me siento muy incómodo y descolocado si mi agenda no está repleta de actividades.
context: Lenny asks Jerry about his famous piece of advice involving a question that contains the word 'complicit.' Jerry explains this as a foundational coaching question designed to help people recognize their own role in creating situations they claim to dislike. He emphasizes that 'complicit' doesn't mean 'responsible' - it's more like being an accomplice rather than the main perpetrator. The purpose is to help people discover their own agency and stop deluding themselves about patterns they unconsciously perpetuate.
vocabulary_highlights: been complicit, evoke your own agency, diluting yourself, unnerved and disconcerted, jam-packed
topics: Coaching & Development, Leadership & Management, Decision Making

speaker: Jerry Colonna
speaker_expertise: Executive Coaching, Leadership Development, Company Building
text: We're socialized to bullshit not only ourselves, but everybody else, especially in the entrepreneurial community. All our companies are moving up into the right. Every product is working. We don't really have any problems because we're crushing it, and that's just a lie.
text_ko: 우리는 자기 자신뿐 아니라 다른 사람들에게도, 특히 기업가 커뮤니티(entrepreneurial community)에서는 서로 허풍을 떨도록 사회화돼 있어요. '우리 회사들 다 우상향(moving up into the right) 하고 있고, 모든 제품이 잘 돌아가서 문제 같은 건 없어요. 우리는 완전 잘나가고 있어요(crushing it).' 그런데 그건 그냥 거짓말이에요.
text_zh: 我们从小就被教育要扯淡，不光对自己扯淡，对所有人都扯淡，特别是在创业圈里。我们的公司都在蒸蒸日上，每个产品都很成功，我们没有任何问题，因为我们正在碾压市场——这些都是扯淡。
text_es: Nos enseñan a vendernos humo no solo a nosotros mismos, sino a todos los demás, especialmente en el mundo emprendedor. Todas nuestras empresas van viento en popa. Todos los productos funcionan de maravilla. En realidad no tenemos problemas porque la estamos rompiendo, y eso es pura mentira.
context: Jerry discusses how people in business, particularly entrepreneurs, are conditioned to present false narratives about their success and wellbeing. He points out the culture of always claiming everything is going perfectly - companies are growing, products are successful, and there are no real problems. Jerry identifies this as a fundamental dishonesty that prevents people from addressing real issues and getting the help they need.
vocabulary_highlights: we're socialized to bullshit, moving up into the right, we're crushing it
topics: Leadership & Management, Starting a Company, Communication Skills

speaker: Jerry Colonna
speaker_expertise: Executive Coaching, Leadership Development, Company Building
text: And when he woke up, he woke up to the four noble truths and the four noble truths are life is filled with suffering, that which we do to push away suffering increases suffering. The third noble truth is that there's an end to suffering. And the fourth noble truth is what's known as the eightfold path to the end of suffering.
text_ko: 그가 깨어났을 때 사성제(four noble truths)를 알게 되었어요. 사성제는 삶이 고통으로 가득하다는 것, 고통을 밀어내려고 하는 행동이 오히려 그 고통을 더 키운다는 것, 셋째는 고통에는 끝이 있다는 것, 넷째는 그 끝에 이르는 길로 알려진 팔정도(eightfold path)예요.
text_zh: 他醒悟的时候，领悟了四圣谛。四圣谛就是：第一，人生充满痛苦；第二，我们越想摆脱痛苦，痛苦反而越多；第三，痛苦是可以结束的；第四，有一条八正道(eightfold path)可以让我们摆脱痛苦。
text_es: Y cuando despertó, se dio cuenta de las cuatro nobles verdades: la primera es que la vida está llena de sufrimiento, la segunda es que todo lo que hacemos para evitar el sufrimiento en realidad lo aumenta. La tercera noble verdad es que sí se puede acabar con el sufrimiento. Y la cuarta es lo que se conoce como el sendero óctuple (eightfold path) para terminar con el sufrimiento.
context: Lenny asks Jerry how to help people feel comfortable with potentially losing financial comfort and material possessions when pursuing more meaningful work. Jerry responds by referencing Buddhist teachings, specifically the story of Buddha's enlightenment and the four noble truths. He explains these foundational Buddhist concepts to illustrate how our attempts to avoid discomfort through material acquisition often increase our suffering rather than reducing it.
vocabulary_highlights: he woke up to, four noble truths, push away suffering, eightfold path
topics: Work-Life Balance, Decision Making, Learning & Growth

speaker: Jerry Colonna
speaker_expertise: Executive Coaching, Leadership Development, Company Building
text: Teams are groups, and there are group dynamics that always happen. There is the scapegoat, there is the truth-teller who has to say, 'Let me tell you what's really wrong with everything going on.' Without the individual's radical self-inquiry skills, groups tend to be condemned to repeating patterns oftentimes of their family of origin.
text_ko: 팀은 결국 집단이고, 늘 생기는 집단 역학(group dynamics)이 있어요. 희생양(scapegoat)이 등장하기도 하고, '지금 벌어지고 있는 일들에서 뭐가 진짜 문제인지 내가 말해줘야겠다'고 하는 진실을 말하는 사람(truth-teller)도 있어요. 개인이 근본적인 자기성찰 능력(radical self-inquiry skills)을 갖추지 못하면, 팀은 원가족(family of origin)의 반복적 패턴을 자주 되풀이하게 되는 경우가 많아요.
text_zh: 团队就是一个群体，群体里面总是会有各种各样的动态。肯定会有背锅的人，也会有那种敢说真话的人，就是那种会站出来说"我来告诉你们到底哪里出了问题"的人。如果团队成员没有深度自省的能力，那这个群体就很容易陷入重复的模式，往往还是从原生家庭带来的那些模式。
text_es: Los equipos son grupos, y siempre se dan esas dinámicas grupales que ya conocemos. Está el chivo expiatorio, está el que dice las verdades y que tiene que saltar con "déjame decirte qué es lo que realmente está mal con todo esto que pasa". Sin las habilidades de autoexploración radical (radical self-inquiry) de cada persona, los grupos tienden a estar condenados a repetir patrones, muchas veces los mismos de su familia de origen.
context: Lenny asks Jerry what often causes teams and companies to fail, noting that it's rarely due to lack of talent, strategy, or execution. Jerry explains that team dysfunction typically stems from unresolved personal issues that team members bring from their past. He describes how teams unconsciously recreate familiar dysfunctional patterns from their childhood families, and how specific roles like 'scapegoat' and 'truth-teller' emerge in groups when individuals haven't done the internal work to understand their own patterns.
vocabulary_highlights: group dynamics, the scapegoat, the truth-teller, condemned to repeating patterns, family of origin
topics: Leadership & Management, Coaching & Development, Communication Skills

speaker: Jerry Colonna
speaker_expertise: Executive Coaching, Leadership Development, Company Building
text: Carl Jung once said, 'Until you make the unconscious conscious, it will direct your life and you will call it fate.' Let's apply it here. Until you make conscious the unconscious patterns operating in the group, the group will continue to repeat those patterns and you will blame somebody in the group.
text_ko: 칼 융은 "무의식(unconscious)을 의식(conscious)으로 만들기 전까지는 그게 당신의 삶을 이끌고, 당신은 그걸 운명이라고 부르게 될 거예요"라고 말했어요. 여기서 적용해 보면, 팀 안에서 작동하는 무의식적 패턴(unconscious patterns)을 의식으로 끌어올리지 않으면 팀은 그 패턴을 계속 반복하고 결국 팀 안의 누구를 탓하게 될 거예요.
text_zh: 荣格曾经说过："你不把潜意识的东西意识化，它就会操控你的人生，而你还以为这是命运。" 放到我们这里也是一样的道理。如果你不把团队里那些潜在的运作模式(unconscious patterns)给挖出来、看清楚，这个团队就会一直重复这些老毛病，到时候你肯定又要怪团队里的某个人了。
text_es: Carl Jung dijo una vez: "Mientras no hagas consciente lo inconsciente, esto dirigirá tu vida y tú lo llamarás destino." Apliquémoslo aquí. Mientras no te des cuenta de los patrones inconscientes que operan en el equipo, el grupo va a seguir repitiendo esos mismos patrones y tú vas a terminar echándole la culpa a alguien del equipo.
context: Jerry continues explaining why teams fail, building on his point about unresolved personal issues creating team dysfunction. He quotes Carl Jung to illustrate how unconscious patterns control our behavior until we become aware of them. Jerry applies this psychological principle to team dynamics, explaining that groups will keep repeating dysfunctional patterns and scapegoating individual members unless they recognize and address the underlying unconscious dynamics at play.
vocabulary_highlights: make the unconscious conscious, call it fate, unconscious patterns operating
topics: Leadership & Management, Coaching & Development, Strategy & Planning

speaker: Jerry Colonna
speaker_expertise: Executive Coaching, Leadership Development, Company Building
text: What I always hope from all of these intimate conversations that I try to do in podcasts is that people walk away going, 'Geez, I'm not alone.' We've made different references to the fact that it's a hard time. The truth is it's always a hard time. And what makes it hardest is to feel like I'm the only one who's going through this.
text_ko: 제가 팟캐스트(podcast)에서 이렇게 친밀한 대화를 나눌 때마다 늘 바라는 건, 사람들이 듣고 나서 '아, 나만 그런 게 아니구나'라고 느끼고 가는 거예요. 우리가 여러 번 지금이 힘든 시기라고 얘기했지만, 사실 인생은 늘 힘든 시기예요. 그리고 그중에서도 가장 힘든 건 이걸 나만 겪고 있는 것처럼 느껴지는 거예요.
text_zh: 我做播客(podcast)时总是希望通过这些深入的对话，让大家听完后会想："哎呀，原来我不是一个人在战斗。" 我们刚才也提到了现在这个时期很艰难。但说实话，什么时候都不容易。最难熬的就是觉得只有我一个人在经历这些。
text_es: Lo que siempre espero de todas estas conversaciones más íntimas que trato de hacer en los podcasts es que la gente se vaya pensando: "Ay, no estoy solo en esto." Hemos mencionado varias veces que son tiempos difíciles. La verdad es que siempre son tiempos difíciles. Y lo que más duele es sentir que soy el único que está pasando por esto.
context: As the podcast concludes, Lenny asks Jerry if there's any final wisdom he'd like to share. Jerry reflects on his hope for all podcast conversations - that listeners feel less alone in their struggles. He acknowledges that while people often think current times are uniquely difficult, life has always been challenging. Jerry emphasizes that the most difficult part of any hardship is the isolation and feeling that you're the only one experiencing these problems.
vocabulary_highlights: intimate conversations, walk away going, it's always a hard time
topics: Communication Skills, Coaching & Development, Work-Life Balance

speaker: Jessica Lachs
speaker_expertise: Data Analytics, Metrics Definition, Business Impact Analysis
text: For me, analytics is a business impact driving function and not purely a service function, not just answering the why, but answering the, 'What do we do now that we know this?' For me, it's about finding opportunities, about having a point of view on the decisions that we should make, not just answering the why but answering the so what. 'So what do we do now that we know this?'
text_ko: 저한텐 애널리틱스(analytics)가 단순한 서비스 기능이 아니라 비즈니스 임팩트를 만들어내는 역할이에요. 단지 '왜 그랬는지'를 설명해주는 데 그치지 않고, '이걸 알게 됐으니 이제 우리가 뭘 해야 하나요?'에 답할 수 있어야 해요. 기회를 찾아내고 우리가 내려야 할 결정에 대해 관점을 갖는 거예요. '왜'를 넘어 '그게 그래서 무슨 의미인지(so what)?'와 '이걸 알았으니 이제 우리가 뭘 할 건가요?'까지 말해주는 거예요.
text_zh: 在我看来，数据分析(analytics)不只是个服务部门，而是能直接推动业务成果的核心职能。我们不能只回答"为什么"，更要回答"知道了这个，我们接下来该怎么办？"对我来说，关键是发现机会，对我们应该做什么决策提出自己的观点和建议。不只是解释原因，更要回答"然后呢？知道了这些信息，我们具体该采取什么行动？"
text_es: Para mí, la analítica es una función que realmente impulsa el impacto en el negocio, no es solo una función de servicio que responde el porqué de las cosas, sino que también responde: "¿Y ahora qué hacemos con esta información?" Se trata de identificar oportunidades, de tener una posición clara sobre las decisiones que deberíamos tomar, no solo explicar el porqué sino también el "¿y qué?" O sea, "¿qué hacemos ahora que sabemos esto?"
context: Lenny asks Jessica about her contrarian perspective on how to structure data teams within companies.
