Jessica explains her philosophy that analytics should be a strategic business partner rather than just a support function. She believes data teams should have a seat at the table alongside engineering and product teams, proactively finding opportunities and making recommendations rather than simply answering questions or building dashboards through service tickets.
vocabulary_highlights: business impact driving function, service function, so what

speaker: Jessica Lachs
speaker_expertise: Data Analytics, Metrics Definition, Business Impact Analysis
text: Retention is a terrible thing to goal on. It's almost impossible to drive in a meaningful way in a short term. Ultimately, you want to find a short-term metric you can measure that drives a long-term output.
text_ko: 리텐션(retention)을 목표로 삼는 건 별로예요. 단기간에 의미 있게 끌어올리기는 거의 불가능해요. 결국엔 장기 성과(long-term output)를 만들어내는, 측정 가능한 단기 지표(short-term metric)를 찾아서 거기에 집중해야 해요.
text_zh: 把留存当目标真的很坑。短期内想有效提升留存几乎不可能。说到底，你得找个能在短期内衡量的指标，这个指标能带动长期的结果。
text_es: La retención es pésima como objetivo. Es casi imposible moverla de manera significativa a corto plazo. Al final, lo que necesitas es encontrar una métrica de corto plazo que puedas medir y que impulse un resultado a largo plazo.
context: Lenny mentions that Jessica is incredibly good at defining metrics and asks about her approach to picking good metrics and aligning incentives. Jessica explains her framework for metric selection, emphasizing that teams should focus on actionable short-term metrics rather than long-term outcomes that are difficult to influence quickly. She argues that retention, while important as an outcome, is not effective as a goal because teams can't impact it meaningfully in the short term.
vocabulary_highlights: goal on, drives a long-term output

speaker: Jessica Lachs
speaker_expertise: Data Analytics, Metrics Definition, Business Impact Analysis
text: Yes, you are a data scientist, but your goal is to figure out what's happening. And if that means that you're going to pick up the phone and call customers, then that is what you're going to do to roll up your sleeves.
text_ko: 맞아요, 데이터 사이언티스트(data scientist)이긴 하지만 목표는 무슨 일이 일어나고 있는지 알아내는 거예요. 고객에게 전화를 걸어야 한다면 팔을 걷어붙이고 직접 전화해서 물어보면 돼요.
text_zh: 没错，你是个数据科学家，但你的目标是要搞清楚到底发生了什么。如果这意味着你得拿起电话给客户打电话，那你就得撸起袖子这么干。
text_es: Sí, eres científico de datos, pero tu objetivo es entender qué está pasando. Y si eso significa que vas a tomar el teléfono y llamar a los clientes, pues eso es lo que vas a hacer para arremangarte y meterte de lleno.
context: Lenny asks Jessica about creating extreme ownership within teams, referencing the early DoorDash culture. Jessica explains her expectation that team members should take complete ownership of outcomes rather than staying within traditional role boundaries. She describes how data scientists on her team will do whatever is necessary to solve problems, including qualitative research like customer calls when quantitative data isn't sufficient to understand issues.
vocabulary_highlights: roll up your sleeves

speaker: Jessica Lachs
speaker_expertise: Data Analytics, Metrics Definition, Business Impact Analysis
text: I became a data scientist out of necessity. I completely self-taught in terms of SQL and Python and I did it because there was a need at DoorDash for someone to help figure out what the right goals were, how we set those goals, how we were performing different markets early in the DoorDash story, so 10 years ago at this point.
text_ko: 저는 필요 때문에 데이터 사이언티스트(data scientist)가 되었어요. SQL(SQL)과 Python(Python)은 전부 독학했어요. 당시 DoorDash에는 누군가가 올바른 목표가 무엇인지, 그 목표를 어떻게 설정할지, 그리고 DoorDash 초창기 각 시장의 성과가 어땠는지를 파악해줄 사람이 필요했기 때문에 그렇게 했어요. 지금으로부터 약 10년 전 일이에요.
text_zh: 我是被逼成数据科学家的。SQL和Python(Python)都是我自学的，当时DoorDash急需有人帮忙搞清楚我们的目标到底应该是什么，怎么定这些目标，还有在DoorDash早期阶段各个市场的表现怎么样，那已经是十年前的事了。
text_es: Me convertí en científico de datos por necesidad. Aprendí SQL y Python completamente por mi cuenta porque en DoorDash hacía falta alguien que ayudara a entender cuáles eran los objetivos correctos, cómo establecer esas metas, y cómo nos estaba yendo en los diferentes mercados al principio de la historia de DoorDash, hace ya unos 10 años.
context: Lenny notes that Jessica doesn't have a traditional data science background, having previously had an art portfolio and worked in investment banking. Jessica explains how she transitioned into data science by teaching herself technical skills out of business necessity at DoorDash. She acknowledges that she jokes about having a job she'd never be hired for today due to her non-traditional background, but that Tony Xu recognized her capabilities despite her lack of formal training.
vocabulary_highlights: out of necessity, self-taught

speaker: Jessica Lachs
speaker_expertise: Data Analytics, Metrics Definition, Business Impact Analysis
text: I think it happened organically and I don't think I realized at the time what I was even doing. And then I think if you think about things from first principles about what you need right now in front of you to unblock yourself or solve a problem, and you just focus on that instead of thinking about a global org that you're trying to build.
text_ko: 제 생각엔 그게 자연스럽게 생긴 일이라서, 그때 제가 뭘 하고 있는지도 잘 몰랐던 것 같아요. 그리고 지금 눈앞에 있는 문제를 풀거나 막힌 걸 뚫기 위해 당장 필요한 게 뭔지 기본 원리(first principles)에서 생각해 보면, 큰 조직을 만들겠다고 고민하는 대신 그거에만 집중하는 게 더 낫다고 생각해요.
text_zh: 我觉得这个过程很自然，当时我也没意识到自己在做什么。我觉得如果你从第一性原理(first principles)的角度去思考，就想想眼前需要什么来解决卡壳的问题，专注于此就行了，而不是去想着要搭建一个全球性的组织架构。
text_es: Creo que pasó de forma natural y en ese momento ni me daba cuenta de lo que estaba haciendo realmente. Y después creo que si piensas las cosas desde los fundamentos básicos (first principles) sobre lo que necesitas ahora mismo, justo enfrente de ti, para desbloquearte o resolver un problema, y te enfocas solo en eso en lugar de estar pensando en toda una organización global que estás tratando de construir.
context: Lenny asks Jessica what she thinks allowed her to succeed in data science despite not having a traditional background in the field. Jessica reflects on her approach of focusing on immediate problems rather than overthinking her lack of credentials. She describes how she learned skills incrementally - first asking engineers for data access, then learning Python when that became a bottleneck - by thinking from first principles about what was needed to solve each immediate challenge.
vocabulary_highlights: from first principles, unblock yourself, global org

speaker: Jessica Lachs
speaker_expertise: Data Analytics, Metrics Definition, Business Impact Analysis
text: I think keeping things simple is another thing I've learned over the years, maybe it's data scientists, but they tend to love these composite metrics with a coefficient. 'We're going to wait this input at X and this input at X+2.' And then you end up with a metric that nobody really understands that doesn't actually mean anything.
text_ko: 제가 수년 동안 배운 것 중 하나는, 뭔가를 단순하게 유지하는 거예요. 아마 데이터 사이언티스트들(data scientists) 탓일 수도 있는데, 이분들은 계수(coefficient)가 들어간 합성 지표(composite metrics)를 좋아하는 경향이 있어요. “이 입력에는 가중치(weight)를 X로, 저 입력에는 X+2로 하자”라고 하고 나면 결국 아무도 제대로 이해하지 못하는, 사실상 아무 의미 없는 지표가 나오고 말아요.
text_zh: 我觉得保持简单是我这些年学到的另一个道理。可能是数据科学家的通病吧，他们特别爱搞那些复合指标(composite metrics)，还要加系数。什么"这个输入我们按X权重，那个输入按X+2权重"。最后整出来一个指标，没人能看懂，其实也没什么实际意义。
text_es: Creo que mantener las cosas sencillas es algo que he aprendido con los años. Tal vez sea cosa de los científicos de datos, pero tienden a enamorarse de estas métricas compuestas con coeficientes. "Vamos a ponderar esta variable con X y esta otra con X+2." Y al final terminas con una métrica que nadie entiende realmente y que no significa nada en la práctica.
context: Lenny asks Jessica about her approach to picking good metrics and aligning incentives. Jessica shares her philosophy on metric design, explaining that data scientists often create overly complex composite metrics with weighted coefficients that are difficult for teams to understand and act upon. She advocates for simple, intuitive metrics that people across the company can easily comprehend and work toward, even if they're not mathematically perfect.
vocabulary_highlights: composite metrics, coefficient

speaker: Jessica Hische
text: Most people are better at understanding the feelings and sensations that typography and logos give us than they give themselves credit for, because what we are as people are endless absorbers of patterns, and information, and all this kind of stuff as we move throughout the world. We don't take time to sit and digest it, but it's still coming in and getting logged, and so even as a non-designer, I think you can look at examples of logos where something's not quite right and be like, "Something's not right here, I just don't know how to name it."
text_ko: 대부분 사람들은 타이포그래피(typography)나 로고(logo)가 주는 느낌과 감각을 스스로 생각하는 것보다 훨씬 잘 이해해요. 우리는 사람으로서 세상을 돌아다니며 끊임없이 패턴이나 정보 같은 걸 흡수하는 존재거든요. 그걸 앉아서 곱씹을 시간은 잘 내지 않지만, 어쨌든 계속 들어오고 기록되고 있어요. 그래서 디자이너가 아니어도 뭔가 좀 어긋난 로고를 보면 “여기 뭔가 이상한데, 어떻게 설명해야 할지는 모르겠네” 하고 느낄 수 있다고 생각해요.
text_zh: 其实大多数人对字体和logo给我们的感觉和印象，理解能力比他们自己想象的要强得多。因为我们人本身就是无时无刻不在吸收各种模式、信息这些东西的，我们在这个世界上到处走动的时候都在接收。虽然我们平时不会专门坐下来消化这些，但这些信息还是在不断进入我们的大脑并被记录下来。所以我觉得即使你不是设计师，你也能看出一些logo哪里不太对劲，就是那种"感觉这里有问题，但我说不上来是什么"的感觉。
text_es: La mayoría de la gente es mucho mejor de lo que cree para entender las emociones y sensaciones que nos transmiten la tipografía y los logos, porque como seres humanos somos como esponjas que absorben patrones, información y todo este tipo de cosas mientras nos movemos por el mundo. No nos damos el tiempo de sentarnos a procesarlo conscientemente, pero igual está entrando y quedándose grabado, así que incluso si no eres diseñador, creo que puedes ver ejemplos de logos donde algo no cuadra y decir "aquí hay algo que no está bien, solo que no sé cómo explicarlo."
context: Lenny asks Jessica how non-designers can learn to see design through a designer's eyes, since most listeners are product managers, founders, and engineers rather than designers. Jessica explains that people are naturally good at recognizing design patterns and feelings from typography and logos, even if they can't articulate why. She emphasizes that humans constantly absorb visual information as they move through the world, and this gives them an intuitive sense of when something feels "off" about a design, even without formal design training.
vocabulary_highlights: give themselves credit for, endless absorbers, coming in and getting logged, something's not quite right

speaker: Jessica Hische
text: I come in then to take the existing vibe and smooth it out, address any of the concerns that came up. A lot of times, it's really utilitarian stuff like this doesn't scale well, or this thing falls apart in this context, or we never had a good avatar version of it, or whatever. Sometimes it's really specific utilitarian fixes, and sometimes it's just about growing it up and sophisticated it without losing what was there in the first place that people got excited about.
text_ko: 제가 들어가서 기존 분위기를 이어받아 매끄럽게 다듬고, 제기된 문제들을 하나하나 해결해요. 많은 경우는 진짜 실용적인 문제들이어서 “이건 확장성이 안 되네”, “이 맥락에서는 이 부분이 무너지네”, “이걸 보여줄 좋은 아바타(avatar) 버전이 없었네” 같은 얘기들이에요. 때로는 아주 구체적인 실무적 수정이고, 때로는 사람들이 처음에 흥분했던 그 느낌을 잃지 않으면서 전체를 더 성숙하고 세련되게 만드는 일이에요.
text_zh: 我进来之后，就是把现有的感觉理顺一下，解决一些冒出来的问题。很多时候都是些很实用的东西，比如说这个扩展性不好，或者放到那个场景里就不行了，或者我们一直没做过好的头像版本，诸如此类的。有时候是很具体的实用性修复，有时候就是让它更成熟更精细，但不能丢掉一开始让大家兴奋的那些东西。
text_es: Entonces entro yo para tomar esa vibra que ya existe y pulirla, resolver cualquier problema que haya surgido. La mayoría de las veces son cosas muy prácticas como que esto no escala bien, o que esta cosa se cae en este contexto, o que nunca tuvimos una buena versión avatar de esto, o lo que sea. A veces son arreglos muy específicos y prácticos, y a veces se trata simplemente de hacerlo crecer y sofisticarlo sin perder lo que tenía desde el principio que emocionó a la gente.
context: Lenny asks Jessica to describe her approach to logo and brand refreshes. Jessica explains her philosophy that startups shouldn't invest heavily in branding from the beginning because they may need to pivot, but once they become successful, they shouldn't be locked into whatever they hastily created for early investor meetings. She describes her role as coming in to refine and professionalize existing branding while maintaining the elements that made it successful in the first place.
vocabulary_highlights: smooth it out, utilitarian stuff, falls apart in this context, growing it up and sophisticated it

speaker: Jessica Hische
text: One of the reasons why I tell people why having a custom logo or custom typography can really matter is that if you're using something that's available to everyone, the chances of someone else coming in and copying you are very easy and high. You might be one of these lucky companies that just out the gate is outrageously successful, but with success comes people climbing up behind you trying to copy your success.
text_ko: 제가 사람들이 왜 맞춤 로고(custom logo)나 맞춤 타이포그래피(custom typography)를 갖는 게 중요한지 말하는 이유 중 하나는, 누구나 쓸 수 있는 걸 쓰면 다른 사람이 와서 쉽게 베낄 가능성이 훨씬 커지기 때문이에요. 처음부터 대성공을 거두는 운 좋은 회사일 수도 있지만, 성공하면 뒤에서 따라와서 그 성공을 따라 하려는 사람들이 생겨요.
text_zh: 我经常跟人说，为什么定制logo或者定制字体真的很重要，就是因为如果你用的是大家都能用的东西，别人要抄你就太容易了，概率也特别高。你可能是那种很幸运的公司，一出来就特别成功，但是成功了之后，肯定会有人跟在后面想要复制你的成功模式。
text_es: Una de las razones por las que siempre les digo a la gente que tener un logo personalizado o una tipografía propia puede hacer toda la diferencia es que si usas algo que está disponible para todo el mundo, las posibilidades de que alguien más llegue y te copie son súper altas y súper fáciles. Puede que seas una de esas empresas afortunadas que desde el primer día le pega al clavo y tiene un éxito tremendo, pero con el éxito viene gente que se te trepa atrás tratando de copiar tu fórmula.
context: Lenny asks Jessica about signs that it might be time to upgrade from a basic logo to something more professional. Jessica discusses the importance of custom branding, especially when companies are preparing to invest money in physical materials like swag or conference materials. She explains that using widely available fonts or design elements makes it easy for competitors to copy your brand identity, which becomes a bigger risk as companies grow more successful.
vocabulary_highlights: out the gate, outrageously successful, climbing up behind you

speaker: Jessica Hische
text: I'm not opposed to Frankensteining options together. To me, it's like I'm giving you a menu of all the things that we can do, but I'm like a chef that puts a menu together where you can combine different appetizers and different mains and they all still make sense. Some people will give you a menu and if you try to do that, it's insane and it tastes terrible. But for me, everything that we're doing, I feel like, mixes and matches fairly well.
text_ko: 옵션들을 프랑켄슈타인식 조합(Frankensteining)으로 이어붙이는 걸 반대하지 않아요. 제 입장에선 우리가 할 수 있는 모든 선택지를 메뉴로 드리는 건데, 저는 마치 셰프처럼 전채와 메인을 여러 개 골라 조합해도 다 어울리게 메뉴를 짜주는 사람이에요. 어떤 사람들은 메뉴를 그렇게 내놓으면, 그걸 조합해보면 말도 안 되고 맛도 엉망이에요. 하지만 제 경우엔 우리가 하는 모든 것들이 서로 꽤 잘 섞이고 어울린다고 느껴요.
text_zh: 我不反对把各种方案拼拼凑凑组合在一起。对我来说，就像我给你一份菜单，上面有我们能做的所有事情，但我就像个厨师，设计的菜单让你可以随意搭配不同的开胃菜和主菜，而且怎么搭都合理。有些人给你的菜单，你要是这么搭配的话，那就乱套了，味道也会很糟糕。但对我来说，我们做的所有事情，我觉得都能很好地mix and match（混搭组合）。
text_es: No me opongo a armar algo tipo Frankenstein combinando opciones. Para mí es como si te diera un menú de todo lo que podemos hacer, pero soy como un chef que arma un menú donde puedes combinar diferentes entradas y diferentes platos fuertes y todo sigue teniendo sentido. Hay gente que te da un menú y si tratas de hacer eso, es una locura y sabe horrible. Pero en mi caso, todo lo que estamos haciendo, siento que se mezcla y combina bastante bien.
context: Lenny mentions that during their logo refresh process, he changed direction after they had narrowed down options, asking to go back and explore different approaches. Jessica explains her flexible approach to client feedback, using a cooking metaphor to describe how she designs logo elements that can be combined in different ways. She contrasts her method with other designers who might be more rigid about not mixing different design directions together.
vocabulary_highlights: Frankensteining options together, mixes and matches fairly well, tastes terrible

speaker: Jessica Hische
text: I feel like a lot of clients come to me and they have hot ham water when it comes to their brand. It's just about turning that into a soup, something that feels real.
text_ko: 많은 클라이언트들이 제게 오면 자기 브랜드에 대해 사실상 실체가 없는, '핫 햄 워터(hot ham water)' 같은 상태를 가지고 오는 것 같아요. 제 일은 그걸 수프처럼 실감 나고 진짜로 느껴지는 무언가로 바꿔주는 거예요.
text_zh: 我发现很多客户来找我的时候，他们的品牌就像是泡火腿的水一样，没什么味道。我要做的就是把它变成一锅好汤，让人感觉有血有肉的。
text_es: Siento que muchos clientes llegan a mí con una marca que está como agua tibia con jamón, ¿sabes? Se trata de convertir eso en una sopa de verdad, algo que se sienta auténtico.
context: Jessica uses a cooking analogy to explain brand cohesion, comparing her move from New York (where she never cooked) to San Francisco (where she learned to cook). She describes how early cooking attempts result in ingredients that don't work together, but with experience you learn to create cohesive dishes. She applies this to branding, explaining that many clients come to her with disparate brand elements that don't feel unified, and her job is to make everything feel like it was created together.
vocabulary_highlights: hot ham water

speaker: Jessica Hische
text: It's cool because you are reverse-justifying decisions. I think that's a really fun exercise to do, is to Song Exploder your intuition. You make a decision intuitively or look at something and intuit what you feel from it, and then really try to dive in, "Why do I feel that way? What could this have reminded me of that made me feel that way?"
text_ko: 결정을 거꾸로 정당화하는 방식(reverse-justifying decisions)이라 멋져요. 저는 그게 정말 재밌는 연습이라고 생각해요 — 직관을 Song Exploder 방식(Song Exploder)으로 분해해 보는 거예요. 직관적으로 결정을 내리거나 뭔가를 보고 직관적으로 느낀 다음에 “왜 내가 그렇게 느꼈지? 이게 뭘 떠올리게 해서 그런 감정을 준 걸까?”라고 깊게 파고드는 거예요.
text_zh: 这个很有意思，因为你是在反向论证自己的决定。我觉得这是个特别好玩的练习，就是把你的直觉给"解构"一下。你凭直觉做了个决定，或者看到什么东西凭感觉判断，然后真的深挖一下，"我为什么会有这种感觉？这可能让我想到了什么，所以才有这种感觉？"
text_es: Me parece genial porque estás justificando las decisiones al revés. Creo que es un ejercicio súper interesante hacer un "Song Exploder" de tu intuición. Tomas una decisión de manera intuitiva o miras algo y sientes lo que te transmite, y luego te metes a fondo: "¿Por qué siento esto? ¿Qué me pudo haber recordado esto que me hizo sentir así?"
context: Jessica continues explaining how people can develop their design intuition by examining why certain fonts or designs make them feel specific ways. She suggests that feelings about design often come from personal associations - for example, a font might remind someone of being 22 at a band show, which creates a specific emotional response. She encourages people to analyze their intuitive reactions to understand the underlying reasons for their design preferences.
vocabulary_highlights: reverse-justifying decisions, Song Exploder your intuition

speaker: Jessica Hische
text: My goal always when designing a logo is to design a logo that's so easy to use that you don't have to be an extremely skilled designer to design well with it. That's my number one goal, because I know not everybody is going to be at a stage where they have an internal brand team or a designer that's a rock star designer that can work with really complicated assets and make them look good.
text_ko: 제가 로고(logo)를 디자인할 때 늘 가장 중요하게 생각하는 건, 굉장히 숙련된 디자이너가 아니어도 잘 활용할 수 있을 만큼 사용하기 쉬운 로고를 만드는 거예요. 이게 제 최우선 목표예요. 모든 회사가 내부 브랜드팀(brand team)이나 복잡한 애셋(assets)을 다루고 멋지게 소화해 줄 스타급 디자이너를 갖춘 단계에 있지는 않다는 걸 알고 있기 때문이에요.
text_zh: 我设计logo的时候，最大的目标就是让它用起来特别简单，就算你不是什么设计高手，也能用它做出不错的东西来。这是我的头等大事，因为我知道不是每个公司都有自己的品牌团队，或者有那种超厉害的设计师能把复杂的素材玩得很溜。
text_es: Mi objetivo siempre al diseñar un logo es crear algo tan fácil de usar que no tengas que ser un diseñador súper experimentado para que te quede bien. Esa es mi meta principal, porque sé que no todas las empresas están en una etapa donde tienen un equipo interno de marca o un diseñador crack que pueda trabajar con elementos súper complicados y hacer que se vean increíbles.
context: Jessica explains her philosophy about creating user-friendly brand assets. She discusses how some companies need extensive brand guidelines because their logos are complex, but her approach is different - she aims to create logos that are intuitive to use correctly. She believes that since most startups don't have dedicated brand teams or expert designers, the logo itself should guide people toward using it properly without requiring extensive training or documentation.
vocabulary_highlights: rock star designer, complicated assets

speaker: Jessica Livingston
text: I would look at, do the co-founders get along? Are these people committed? Do they really know about their product? Do they care? Are they going to quit their job? Or are they telling us that they are going to quit their job, but really aren't? All these little social cues that I'd try to pick up on.
text_ko: 제가 보면 공동창업자(co-founders)들 사이가 잘 맞는지 먼저 봐요. 이 사람들이 얼마나 헌신적인지, 제품(product)에 대해 진짜로 잘 알고 있는지, 그리고 진심으로 신경 쓰는지도 중요한 판단 기준이에요. 진짜로 직장을 그만둘 건지, 아니면 그만두겠다고 말은 하지만 실제로는 안 그만둘 건지도 살펴봐요. 이런 작은 사회적 단서들(social cues)까지 다 포착하려고 해요.
text_zh: 我会看，联合创始人之间合得来吗？这些人是不是真心想做这件事？他们对自己的产品到底了不了解？是不是真的用心在做？会不会辞职全身心投入？还是说嘴上说要辞职，其实根本不会？我会努力捕捉这些细微的社交信号。
text_es: Yo me fijaría en, ¿se llevan bien los cofundadores? ¿Esta gente está realmente comprometida? ¿De verdad conocen su producto? ¿Les importa? ¿Van a dejar su trabajo? ¿O nos están diciendo que van a dejarlo pero en realidad no lo van a hacer? Todas estas pequeñas señales sociales que trato de captar.
context: Lenny asks Jessica to explain her "Social Radar" nickname at Y Combinator and how her evaluation approach differed from her technical co-founders. Jessica explains that while her three co-founders (Paul Graham, Robert Morris, and Trevor Blackwell) focused on technical aspects during 10-minute founder interviews, she concentrated on interpersonal dynamics and behavioral cues. She would observe whether co-founders worked well together, if founders were truly committed to their ideas, and whether they would actually quit their day jobs to pursue their startups full-time.
vocabulary_highlights: social cues, pick up on, committed

speaker: Jessica Livingston
text: If a founder would get defensive, that was always a bad sign, always a bad sign. The best founders would say, "Gosh, I have thought about it and here's what I figured out." Or, they just have this almost a tennis match and a conversation rather than closing up and feeling like, oh, this person's interrogating me.
text_ko: 창업자가 방어적으로 나오면 그건 늘 안 좋은 신호였어요. 반대로 잘하는 창업자들은 "정말 생각해봤고, 제가 정리한 건 이거예요"라고 말하거나, 대화를 거의 테니스 경기처럼 주고받으면서 이어가요. 그냥 닫아버리고 '아, 이 사람이 심문하네'라고 느끼게 만드는 식이 아니죠.
text_zh: 如果创始人一听到质疑就开始防御，那绝对是个坏兆头，绝对的坏兆头。最优秀的创始人会说："哎呀，这个问题我想过，我是这么分析的。"或者他们就像打网球一样和你一来一回地讨论，而不是马上把自己封闭起来，觉得："这人是在审问我。"
text_es: Si un fundador se ponía a la defensiva, eso siempre era mala señal, siempre mala señal. Los mejores fundadores decían algo como "Oye, sí he pensado en eso y esto es lo que he descubierto." O simplemente tenían como un ida y vuelta, una conversación fluida en lugar de cerrarse y sentir que, ay, esta persona me está interrogando.
context: Lenny asks Jessica about specific red flags she would look for during Y Combinator interviews. Jessica explains that defensiveness was a major warning sign because successful startups require founders who can handle criticism and questioning from customers, investors, and users. She valued founders who remained open-minded when challenged and could engage in productive dialogue rather than becoming defensive when their ideas were questioned.
vocabulary_highlights: get defensive, tennis match, closing up, interrogating

speaker: Jessica Livingston
text: I remember specifically Joe brought out the cereal boxes, the Obama O's and Cap'n McCain's, and I just thought, oh my God, they're going to work hard to do whatever they can to make this company succeed.
text_ko: 특히 기억나는 건 조가 'Obama O's'랑 'Cap'n McCain's' 시리얼 박스를 꺼냈을 때예요. 그때 저는 '세상에, 이 사람들 이 회사를 성공시키려고 뭐든지 열심히 할 거구나' 하고 생각했어요.
text_zh: 我记得Joe专门拿出那些麦片盒子，什么奥巴马麦片(Obama O's)、麦凯恩船长麦片(Cap'n McCain's)之类的，我当时就想，天哪，这帮人真是拼了，为了让公司成功什么招都使得出来。
text_es: Recuerdo específicamente cuando Joe sacó las cajas de cereal, los Obama O's y los Cap'n McCain's, y pensé "Dios mío, esta gente va a darlo todo para que la empresa triunfe."
context: Lenny asks Jessica to share the famous Airbnb interview story. Jessica explains that during the 2009 financial crisis, Y Combinator was being very selective and only funding scrappy founders who could survive on little money. The Airbnb founders (Brian Chesky, Joe Gebbia, and Nate Blecharczyk) came in with tremendous energy, though Y Combinator actually hated their idea of staying in someone's airbed. At the end of the interview, Joe showed them cereal boxes they had created - Obama O's and Cap'n McCain's - made by repackaging generic cereals, which demonstrated their resourcefulness and determination.
vocabulary_highlights: brought out, going to great lengths

speaker: Jessica Livingston
text: Earnestness is one of the most important because earnest, sort of to me, is bucketed with authenticity. And to be a successful startup founder, you have to care so much about the problem you're trying to solve, the users you're serving and being earnest about it is so key to success.
text_ko: 진정성(authenticity)은 가장 중요한 요소 중 하나예요. 제게 ‘earnestness’는 진정성과 같은 범주에 속해요. 성공적인 스타트업 창업자(startup founder)가 되려면 해결하려는 문제와 서비스를 받는 사용자들에 대해 진심으로 신경 쓰고 몰입해야 하고, 그 진정성이 성공의 핵심이에요.
text_zh: 认真这个品质特别重要，因为在我看来，认真和真诚是一回事。要想做一个成功的创业者，你必须特别在乎你要解决的问题，特别在乎你服务的用户，而且要发自内心地认真对待这件事，这是成功的关键。
text_es: La seriedad de propósito es súper importante porque para mí va de la mano con la autenticidad. Y para ser un fundador exitoso de una startup, tienes que preocuparte muchísimo por el problema que estás tratando de resolver, por los usuarios a los que les estás sirviendo, y ser genuino al respecto es clave para el éxito.
context: Lenny asks Jessica about additional qualities she looks for in founders beyond being hustlers and having domain expertise. Jessica introduces the concept of "earnestness" as one of the most critical traits for successful founders. She explains that earnestness goes hand-in-hand with authenticity - founders must genuinely care about the problems they're solving and the users they're serving, rather than just pursuing startups because it's trendy or they think an idea is cool.
vocabulary_highlights: bucketed with, key to success

speaker: Jessica Livingston
text: You sort of need that desperation like, "I have to make this startup succeed because it's my job." Not like, "Oh, I'll just stay at Google." You need that. And we found that founders who weren't leaving their jobs, it was just not working out.
text_ko: 어느 정도 "'이 스타트업(startup)을 꼭 성공시켜야 해요, 이건 제 일이에요' 하는 절박함이 필요해요. '아, 그냥 구글에 남아있을래요' 식이면 안 돼요. 그리고 저희가 보니까 직장을 그만두지 않는 창업자들(founders)은 잘 안 되더라고요.
text_zh: 你得有那种desperate的感觉，就是"我必须让这个创业公司成功，因为这就是我的饭碗。"而不是"哦，不行我就回谷歌待着。"你必须要有这种心态。我们发现那些不辞职的创始人，基本上都做不成。
text_es: Necesitas como esa desesperación de "tengo que hacer que este startup funcione porque es mi trabajo." No como "ah, me quedo en Google y ya." Eso es fundamental. Y nos dimos cuenta de que los fundadores que no dejaban sus trabajos, simplemente no les funcionaba.
context: Lenny asks Jessica to elaborate on what "commitment" means when evaluating founders. Jessica explains the concept of "burning the boat" - founders need to fully commit by quitting their day jobs because having a safety net often prevents them from pushing through the inevitable difficult periods of building a startup. She notes that Y Combinator discovered that founders who kept their jobs at companies like Google would typically abandon their startups when challenges arose, since they had the security of their regular paycheck and benefits.
vocabulary_highlights: sort of need that desperation, burning the boat, working out

speaker: Jessica Livingston
text: I spent hours and hours on the phone with people, with my girlfriends, dissecting situations, and then all through high school, and college, I mean the amount of time we wasted discussing social matters with people, and boys, and things like that. It was just frightening how much time I wasted, but I just was genuinely interested in it.
text_ko: 사람들이랑, 여자 친구들이랑 전화로 몇 시간이고 상황을 분석하느라 얘기했어요. 그리고 고등학교 때부터 대학 다니는 내내, 그러니까 사람들 얘기나 남자들 얘기 같은 사회적인 일들을 친구들이랑 떠들며 보낸 시간이 진짜 엄청났어요. 얼마나 많은 시간을 낭비했는지 무서울 정도였는데, 그래도 저는 그게 진심으로 궁금하고 흥미로웠어요.
text_zh: 我以前花了大把大把的时间跟朋友们，跟我那些闺蜜聊电话，就是分析各种情况，整个高中、大学期间都这样，我们在讨论人际关系、男生这些事情上浪费的时间，真的多得吓人。现在想想确实浪费了很多时间，但当时我是真的对这些感兴趣。
text_es: Me pasaba horas y horas al teléfono con la gente, con mis amigas, analizando situaciones hasta el cansancio, y después durante toda la preparatoria y la universidad, o sea, la cantidad de tiempo que perdíamos hablando de temas sociales, de chavos, y cosas así. Era impresionante todo el tiempo que desperdiciaba, pero es que de verdad me fascinaba todo eso.
context: Lenny asks Jessica when she first noticed her social radar abilities and whether they were developed or innate. Jessica reflects on her childhood and explains that she's always been fascinated by understanding people's motivations and social dynamics. She describes how even as a young person, she would spend countless hours analyzing interpersonal situations with friends, which she now realizes was early training for her ability to read people and understand what drives them.
vocabulary_highlights: dissecting situations, frightening how much time, genuinely interested

speaker: Jiaona Zhang
text: I think something that is really hard to untrain, but I think every human does it, is you jump to solutions. And so one of the biggest things I see, not just in my course but also just as a PM and some of the mistakes that you make as a PM is the idea of you get really attached to a solution, a way of implementing something that you can see in your head that you want to build.
text_ko: 정말 쉽게 고쳐지지 않는 습관이 하나 있는데, 사람이라면 다들 하는 것 같아요 — 바로 해결책에 성급히 뛰어드는 거예요. 제가 강의에서만이 아니라 PM (product manager)으로 일하면서도 자주 보는 큰 실수 중 하나는, 머릿속에 그려둔 구현 방식(implementation)이나 만들고 싶은 솔루션(solution)에 너무 집착해버리는 거예요.
text_zh: 我觉得有一个特别难改的习惯，但是每个人都会这样做，就是你会直接跳到解决方案上去。所以我发现一个最大的问题，不光是在我的课程里，就是作为产品经理(PM)也是这样，很多产品经理都会犯的错误就是，你会特别执着于某个解决方案，执着于你脑子里想象的那个实现方式，就是你特别想要去做的那个东西。
text_es: Creo que hay algo súper difícil de quitarse de encima, pero que todos hacemos: saltar directo a las soluciones. Y una de las cosas más grandes que veo, no solo en mi curso sino también como PM y algunos de los errores que cometes como PM, es que te enamoras de una solución, de una forma de implementar algo que ya tienes clarísimo en la cabeza y que quieres construir.
context: Lenny asks JZ about the most common mistakes she sees new product managers make, drawing from her six years of teaching product management at Stanford. JZ explains that the biggest mistake new PMs make is jumping straight to solutions without properly understanding user problems first. She emphasizes that this tendency to get attached to specific solutions prevents PMs from focusing on what users actually need.
vocabulary_highlights: hard to untrain, jump to solutions, get really attached to

speaker: Jiaona Zhang
text: You could be known for shepherding like the most complex launches because you're just so good at quarterbacking. Working with go-to--market teams and cross-functional stakeholders that could be like your thing. You could be known for working on the most technically complex problems, find something that you can be really, really good at.
text_ko: 가장 복잡한 런칭(launches)을 총괄해서 이끄는 사람으로 알려질 수 있어요. 쿼터백 역할(quarterbacking)을 정말 잘하니까요. 시장 진입(go-to-market) 팀이나 교차 기능 이해관계자(cross-functional stakeholders)들과 함께 일하는 게 당신의 강점이 될 수 있어요. 또는 가장 기술적으로 복잡한 문제(technically complex problems)를 다루는 일로 이름을 낼 수도 있어요. 정말 잘할 수 있는 무언가를 찾아보세요.
text_zh: 你可以因为特别擅长统筹协调那些最复杂的产品发布而出名，因为你就是很会做项目管理(quarterbacking)。跟市场推广(go-to-market)团队还有各个部门的利益相关方打交道，这可能就是你的强项。你也可以专门攻克那些技术上最复杂的难题，总之要找到一个你能做得特别特别好的领域。
text_es: Podrías ser conocido por liderar los lanzamientos más complejos porque eres increíble coordinando equipos. Trabajar con los equipos de go-to-market y con stakeholders de diferentes áreas podría ser lo tuyo. Podrías ser conocido por resolver los problemas técnicos más difíciles, encuentra algo en lo que puedas ser realmente, pero realmente bueno.
context: Lenny asks JZ for her number one piece of advice to new PMs who want to accelerate their career. JZ explains that it's crucial to become known for being excellent at something specific - whether that's managing complex launches, technical problems, or regulatory issues. She argues that when you build a reputation for excellence in a particular area, you get more responsibility and better projects because people trust you to deliver results.
vocabulary_highlights: shepherding, quarterbacking, cross-functional stakeholders

speaker: Jiaona Zhang
text: My biggest tip on OKRs is actually get really, really crisp on qualitatively. What would make you say "Yes, we did a great job"? And the reason I pushed so hard on that is because I see so many teams get really mucked down by OKRs.
text_ko: OKR에 대한 저의 가장 큰 팁은 사실 질적인 부분에 대해 정말 명확해지는 거예요. "우리가 정말 잘했다!"라고 말할 수 있는 기준이 뭔지 생각해보세요. 제가 이렇게 강조하는 이유는 많은 팀들이 OKR 때문에 정말 힘들어하는 걸 많이 봤거든요.
text_zh: 我对OKRs最大的建议就是，一定要在定性描述上特别特别清晰。什么情况下你会说"对，我们这次干得很棒"？我特别强调这点是因为我见过太多团队在OKRs上搞得一团糟。
text_es: Mi consejo más importante sobre los OKRs es que te enfoques súper bien en lo cualitativo. ¿Qué tendría que pasar para que digas "Sí, lo hicimos genial"? Y insisto tanto en esto porque he visto muchos equipos que se atascan completamente con los OKRs.
context: Lenny asks JZ for her biggest tips on OKRs (Objectives and Key Results). JZ explains that teams often get overwhelmed by OKRs and focus too much on hitting specific numbers rather than understanding the qualitative success they're trying to achieve. She emphasizes the importance of clearly articulating what success looks like before getting caught up in metrics and measurements.
vocabulary_highlights: get really crisp on, mucked down by

speaker: Jiaona Zhang
text: I think the biggest tips I have is how do to be clear about the phase that you're in? So I think it's totally fine to be like, "Hey, we are going to try X for six months, three months, whatever it is, and we're explicitly going to go learn these types of things."
text_ko: 제가 드릴 가장 큰 팁은 지금 어떤 단계인지 분명히 하는 방법이에요. 예를 들어 "저희는 X를 6개월이나 3개월 등 정해진 기간 동안 시도해볼 거고, 그 기간에 구체적으로 이런 것들을 배우는 걸 목표로 삼을 거예요"라고 명확하게 말하는 건 전혀 문제없다고 생각해요.
text_zh: 我觉得最重要的建议就是，你得搞清楚自己现在处在哪个阶段，对吧？我觉得完全可以这样说："嘿，我们打算试试X这个方向，给自己定个期限，六个月也好，三个月也好，就是要专门去摸索这些东西。"
text_es: Creo que el consejo más importante que tengo es ser súper claro sobre en qué etapa estás, ¿no? O sea, me parece perfectamente válido decir: "Oye, vamos a probar X durante seis meses, tres meses, lo que sea, y específicamente vamos a enfocarnos en aprender este tipo de cosas."
context: Lenny asks JZ about when to think big and pursue ambitious goals versus being more cautious about execution. This comes after discussing the Airbnb Plus example, where ambitious vision wasn't coupled with practical execution planning. JZ explains that companies should dream big but be very clear about what phase they're in - whether they're in a learning/prototyping phase or scaling phase - and set explicit milestones and learning goals.
vocabulary_highlights: explicitly going to go learn

speaker: Jiaona Zhang
text: On the product side, it's about really understanding why people love you and not forgetting to invest deeply in that core concept and then building everything around that. And so I'll walk you through the different companies.
text_ko: 제품 측면(product side)에서는 사람들이 왜 여러분을 좋아하는지를 정말로 이해하고, 그 핵심 개념(core concept)에 깊이 투자하는 걸 잊지 않으면서 모든 것을 그걸 중심으로 만들어가는 것이 중요해요. 그래서 이제 제가 여러 회사를 하나씩 소개해 드릴게요.
text_zh: 在产品这块儿，关键是要真正搞清楚用户为什么喜欢你，别忘了在这个核心理念上下重本，然后围绕这个来做所有的东西。所以我给你们讲几个不同公司的例子。
text_es: En cuanto al producto, se trata de entender realmente por qué la gente te ama y no olvidarte de apostar fuerte en ese concepto central, y después construir todo alrededor de eso. Así que te voy a explicar las diferentes empresas.
context: Lenny asks JZ about the biggest lessons she's learned from working at four legendary companies: Dropbox, Airbnb, WeWork, and Webflow. JZ explains that across all these companies, the most important product lesson is understanding your core value proposition - what makes users love your product - and continuing to invest in that strength rather than chasing competitors or spreading resources too thin across multiple initiatives.
vocabulary_highlights: invest deeply in that core concept

speaker: Jiaona Zhang
text: Trust is so important. Trust is everything. As a PM, the trust that your cross-functional partners have in you, the trust that the CEO has is you... It's huge. Trust is everything. And maybe here, I'll even talk about some of the mistakes I made in the first 90 days.
text_ko: 신뢰는 정말 중요해요. 신뢰가 모든 것이죠. PM으로서, 당신의 다양한 파트너들이 당신을 믿는 것, CEO가 당신을 믿는 것... 이건 정말 큰 일이에요. 신뢰가 모든 거예요. 그리고 여기서 제가 처음 90일 동안 저지른 실수에 대해서도 이야기해볼게요.
text_zh: 信任太重要了，信任就是一切。作为PM，你的跨职能合作伙伴对你的信任，CEO对你的信任...这些都太关键了。信任真的就是一切。说到这里，我甚至可以聊聊我在前90天犯的一些错误。
text_es: La confianza es súper importante. La confianza lo es todo. Como PM, la confianza que tengan en ti tus compañeros de otras áreas, la confianza que tenga el CEO en ti... es enorme. La confianza lo es todo. Y tal vez aquí hasta les cuente algunos errores que cometí en mis primeros 90 días.
context: Lenny asks about the importance of building trust during JZ's first 90 days at Webflow, where she had a unique time constraint due to impending maternity leave. JZ emphasizes that trust is fundamental for product managers since they rely on influence rather than authority. She reflects on mistakes she made by pushing for changes too quickly before establishing sufficient trust with her team and stakeholders.
vocabulary_highlights: cross-functional partners

speaker: Joe Hudson
text: I would say every single time the voice in your head is wrong. That critical voice in your head. To be specific, I'm talking about the voice in your head that is critical and repeats. There's the voice that says the same thing over and over again. You got to work out more, you got to work out more, you got to work out more. Whatever that is, it's always wrong, and that doesn't mean there isn't truth to what it says, but it's incorrect.
text_ko: 제 생각엔 머릿속 그 목소리는 매번 틀려요. 그 비판적인 목소리요. 구체적으로 말하면 비판적이고 같은 말을 계속 반복하는 바로 그 목소리를 말하는 거예요. '더 운동해야 해, 더 운동해야 해…'처럼요. 그게 무엇이든 항상 틀려요. 물론 그 말에 진실이 섞여 있을 수는 있지만, 결국엔 옳지 않아요.
text_zh: 我跟你说，脑子里那个声音，十有八九都是错的。就是那个老爱挑毛病的声音。具体来说，我说的是你脑子里那个既爱批评又老是重复的声音。就是那种翻来覆去说同一件事的声音——你得多锻炼，你得多锻炼，你得多锻炼。不管它说什么，基本都是错的。这不是说它说的完全没道理，但它的方式肯定是不对的。
text_es: Yo diría que esa voz en tu cabeza siempre está equivocada. Esa voz crítica que tienes ahí arriba. Para ser específico, me refiero a esa voz en tu cabeza que es crítica y que se repite como disco rayado. Es esa voz que te dice lo mismo una y otra y otra vez. "Tienes que hacer más ejercicio, tienes que hacer más ejercicio, tienes que hacer más ejercicio." Sea lo que sea, siempre está mal, y eso no significa que no haya algo de verdad en lo que dice, pero su enfoque está equivocado.
context: Lenny asks Joe about his insight that the voice in your head is often wrong and contradictory. Joe explains that the critical, repetitive voice in your head - the one that constantly tells you things like "you should work out more" - is always wrong, even when there might be some truth to what it's saying. He argues that this voice isn't actually helping you be productive, despite what most people believe.
vocabulary_highlights: critical voice, repeats, subtext

speaker: Joe Hudson
text: I think the best way to work with the voice in the head is to pick an experiment every day and respond to the voice in the head in a new way every day. One of my favorite responses is, "Oh, I see that you're really scared. Don't worry. I'm right here with you. I got you."
text_ko: 제 생각에는 머릿속의 목소리와 가장 잘 일하는 방법은 매일 하나씩 실험을 골라 그 목소리에 매일 새로운 방식으로 반응해 보는 거예요. 제가 좋아하는 반응 중 하나는 "아, 네가 정말 무서워하구나. 괜찮아요. 내가 여기 같이 있어요. 내가 지켜줄게요."예요.
text_zh: 我觉得对付脑子里那个声音最好的办法，就是每天都试试新招，每天都用不同的方式去回应它。我最喜欢的回应方式是："哦，我看出来你挺害怕的。别担心，我就在这儿陪着你呢，有我在。"
text_es: Creo que la mejor manera de manejar esa voz en la cabeza es elegir un experimento cada día y responderle de una forma nueva cada día. Una de mis respuestas favoritas es: "Ah, veo que tienes mucho miedo. Tranquila. Estoy aquí contigo. Te tengo cubierta."
context: Lenny asks Joe how to practically work with the critical voice in your head. Joe explains that instead of trying to stop or control this voice, you should change how you relate to it. He recommends taking an experimental approach where you respond to the critical voice differently each day, treating it like a scared child rather than an authority figure.
vocabulary_highlights: pick an experiment, I got you

speaker: Joe Hudson
text: It's such an important tool for productivity. If you say, I'm going to figure out how to enjoy what I do 10% more and you succeed, you are 10% more efficient. Not only that, usually, the quality is going to get a lot better too.
text_ko: 정말 생산성(productivity)을 높이는 중요한 도구예요. ‘내가 하는 일을 10% 더 즐기게 만드는 방법을 찾아볼 거야’라고 생각해서 실제로 그렇게 된다면 10% 더 효율적으로 일하게 돼요. 게다가 보통 일의 품질도 훨씬 좋아져요.
text_zh: 这真的是提高工作效率的重要手段。你要是能想办法让自己对工作多享受个10%，那你的效率就能提升10%。不仅如此，通常工作质量也会大幅提升。
text_es: Es una herramienta clave para la productividad. Si te dices, voy a buscar la manera de disfrutar 10% más lo que hago y lo logras, vas a ser 10% más eficiente. Y no solo eso, por lo general la calidad también va a mejorar muchísimo.
context: Lenny asks Joe about his focus on helping people feel joy. Joe explains that enjoyment isn't just about feeling good - it's actually a powerful productivity tool. He argues that if you can learn to enjoy what you're doing even 10% more, you become 10% more efficient and the quality of your work improves significantly.
vocabulary_highlights: tool for productivity, figure out how to

speaker: Joe Hudson
text: Whatever emotion that you're trying to avoid, you are inviting into your life in exactly the way that you're trying to avoid it.
text_ko: 피하려고 애쓰는 감정일수록, 오히려 그걸 피하려는 바로 그 방식대로 삶에 초대하고 있어요.
text_zh: 你越想逃避什么情绪，它就越会以你最不想要的方式出现在你生活里。
text_es: Cualquier emoción que trates de evitar, la estás invitando a tu vida justo de la manera en que intentas evitarla.
context: Lenny asks Joe what is holding people back from success and living the life they want. Joe identifies emotions that people are not sitting with, feeling, or expressing as a major factor. He explains a counterintuitive principle: when you try to avoid feeling a particular emotion, you actually end up experiencing more of that exact emotion in your life.
vocabulary_highlights: inviting into your life, in exactly the way

speaker: Joe Hudson
text: A lot of the people in my circles may have spent hundreds of millions of dollars to try to arrange a life that they enjoy, and it doesn't fucking work.
text_ko: 제 주변 사람들 중 많은 분들이 자기들이 즐길 수 있는 삶을 만들기 위해 수억 달러를 썼을 수도 있는데, 그게 진짜 아무 소용이 없더라고요.
text_zh: 我身边很多人砸了几个亿想要打造自己理想的生活，结果根本不管用。
text_es: Muchos de la gente en mi entorno han gastado cientos de millones de dólares tratando de armar una vida que les guste, y no funciona para nada.
context: Joe is explaining why learning to enjoy what you're currently doing is more powerful than trying to arrange your external circumstances for enjoyment. He notes that many wealthy people he coaches have spent enormous amounts of money trying to create an enjoyable life through external means - buying jets, islands, and luxury items - but this approach fundamentally fails to create lasting satisfaction.
vocabulary_highlights: arrange a life, doesn't fucking work

speaker: Joe Hudson
text: I would do seven minutes, no less than seven minutes. You can do more than seven minutes. Seven minutes of gratitude with another person every day. It has to be feeling the gratitude and then seeing what comes out of your mouth when you're coming from the felt sense of gratitude and doing it back and forth.
text_ko: 저라면 7분은 꼭 하겠어요. 7분보다 짧으면 안 되고, 더 해도 좋아요. 매일 다른 사람과 함께하는 7분간의 감사 시간이요. 중요한 건 감사하는 마음을 진짜로 느끼고, 그 체감되는 감사(felt sense)에서 우러나오는 말을 서로 주고받아 보는 거예요.
text_zh: 我建议每天至少七分钟，不能少于七分钟。你可以做得更久一点。每天和另一个人做七分钟的感恩练习。关键是要真正感受到那种感激之情，然后看看当你发自内心感恩的时候会说出什么话，你们俩就这样互相分享。
text_es: Yo haría siete minutos, no menos de siete minutos. Puedes hacer más de siete minutos si quieres. Siete minutos de gratitud con otra persona todos los días. Tiene que ser sintiendo realmente la gratitud y luego viendo qué sale de tu boca cuando vienes desde esa sensación genuina de agradecimiento, haciéndolo de ida y vuelta entre los dos.
context: Lenny asks Joe for one practical thing everyone can try to become better and more successful. Joe recommends a specific daily gratitude practice: spending exactly seven minutes sharing gratitude back and forth with another person, but emphasizing that it must come from actually feeling the emotion of gratitude in your body, not just intellectual thoughts about what you're grateful for.
vocabulary_highlights: felt sense, back and forth, comes out of your mouth

speaker: Joe Hudson
text: Joy is the matriarch of a family of emotions and she won't come into a house where her children aren't welcome. A very joyful life is a life where all the other emotions are deeply welcomed, not accepted, not non-judgmentally aware of.
text_ko: 기쁨은 감정들의 어머니 같은 존재예요. 그 감정들이 환영받지 못하는 집에는 기쁨이 들어오지 않아요. 진정으로 기쁨이 넘치는 삶은 다른 모든 감정들을 단순히 받아들이거나 판단하지 않는 정도로 알아주는 게 아니라, 깊이 마음으로 환영하는 삶이에요.
text_zh: 快乐就像是情绪大家庭里的老大，如果她的孩子们在这个家里不受欢迎，她是不会进门的。真正快乐的人生，就是要发自内心地拥抱所有其他的情绪，不是简单地接受，也不是那种无所谓的态度。
text_es: La alegría es como la matriarca de toda la familia de emociones, y no va a entrar a una casa donde sus hijos no sean bienvenidos. Una vida realmente plena es aquella donde todas las demás emociones son profundamente bienvenidas, no solo aceptadas o reconocidas sin más.
context: Lenny asks Joe about the difference between non-judgmental awareness of emotions (from meditation practices) and Joe's approach to working with emotions. Joe shares his famous metaphor about joy being like the matriarch of a family - she won't visit a home where her children (other emotions) aren't truly welcome. He emphasizes that emotions need to be welcomed and loved, not just tolerated or observed neutrally.
vocabulary_highlights: matriarch of a family, deeply welcomed, non-judgmentally aware of

speaker: John Cutler
speaker_expertise: Team Building, Leadership Development, Product Management
text: So putting myself in the shoes of those particular companies, like I said, I think some of my most rewarding interactions have been with these non Silicon Valley companies. I certainly learn a lot when I talk to companies in the Bay Area and in the United States to do those particular things.
text_ko: 제가 그 회사들 입장이 돼서 생각해 보면, 말씀드렸듯이 가장 보람 있었던 만남 중 일부는 실리콘밸리 밖에 있는 회사들과의 교류였어요. 물론 베이 에어리어(Bay Area)나 미국에 있는 그런 회사들과 얘기할 때도 많은 걸 배워요.
text_zh: 所以站在那些公司的角度来看，就像我刚才说的，我觉得跟这些非硅谷公司打交道是最有收获的。当然了，跟湾区和美国其他地方的公司聊天，我也学到很多东西。
text_es: Entonces, poniéndome en el lugar de esas empresas en particular, como te decía, creo que algunas de mis interacciones más gratificantes han sido con estas empresas que no son del Silicon Valley. Definitivamente aprendo muchísimo cuando hablo con empresas de la Bahía de San Francisco y de Estados Unidos para hacer esas cosas específicas.
context: Lenny asks John about the differences between Silicon Valley product teams and companies going through digital transformations. John explains that much of the advice available online is geared toward Silicon Valley startups, but most product managers work at companies that don't fit that mold. He shares that some of his most rewarding work has been with non-Silicon Valley companies that are trying to transform their approach to building products.
vocabulary_highlights: putting myself in the shoes of, rewarding interactions, non Silicon Valley

speaker: John Cutler
speaker_expertise: Team Building, Leadership Development, Product Management
text: Part of the thing is just realizing how much inertia they're up against when you're chatting them. So I do believe that there's some structural things that probably they could avoid, but then there's also just structural things that are just part of the game to do that.
text_ko: 일부는 그들과 얘기할 때 그들이 얼마나 큰 관성(inertia)에 맞서고 있는지를 깨닫는 것뿐이에요. 그래서 피할 수 있는 구조적 문제들(structural)이 분명히 있다고 생각해요. 하지만 어쩔 수 없이 그 과정의 일부로 존재하는 구조적 요소들도 있어요.
text_zh: 其实很大一部分原因就是，你跟他们聊的时候会发现，他们面临的阻力有多大。所以我觉得有些结构性的问题他们可能是能避免的，但还有一些结构性的问题就是游戏规则的一部分，没办法。
text_es: Parte del asunto es darse cuenta de cuánta inercia tienen en contra cuando estás hablando con ellos. Así que sí creo que hay algunas cosas estructurales que probablemente podrían evitar, pero también hay cosas estructurales que simplemente son parte del juego para hacer eso.
context: John continues discussing the challenges faced by larger enterprise companies trying to adopt modern product practices. He explains that these companies face significant organizational inertia - resistance to change built into their existing structures and processes. Some structural barriers can be overcome, while others are simply inherent to operating at that scale and in those industries.
vocabulary_highlights: inertia they're up against, part of the game
topics: Product Management, Leadership & Management, Strategy & Planning

speaker: John Cutler
speaker_expertise: Team Building, Leadership Development, Product Management
text: So I think that for a lot of those companies, they see adopting the frameworks as the end goal. They kind of look there. And sometimes maybe even you write a post, it's like, 'Well, how does Figma work?' And they're like, 'We use these frameworks.'
text_ko: 저는 많은 회사들이 프레임워크(frameworks)를 도입하는 걸 그 자체 목표로 보는 것 같아요. 그래서 거기에만 초점을 맞추는 편이고요. 가끔 글을 써서 'Figma가 어떻게 작동하나요?'라고 물어봐도, '우린 이런 프레임워크만 써요'라고만 답하더라고요.
text_zh: 所以我觉得很多公司都把采用这些框架当成最终目标了。他们就盯着这个看。有时候你可能写个帖子问"Figma是怎么运作的？"他们就回答说"我们用这些框架。"
text_es: Entonces creo que muchas de esas empresas ven adoptar los marcos de trabajo (frameworks) como el objetivo final. Como que se enfocan en eso. Y a veces hasta escribes un post preguntando "¿Cómo funciona Figma?" y te responden "Nosotros usamos estos frameworks."
context: John discusses a common mistake that transforming companies make when trying to adopt modern product practices. Instead of understanding the principles behind successful product development, these companies focus on copying the specific frameworks and tools used by successful companies like Figma. John argues this approach misses the point - frameworks should be learning tools, not end goals in themselves.
vocabulary_highlights: end goal, kind of look there

speaker: John Cutler
speaker_expertise: Team Building, Leadership Development, Product Management
text: And so I think that the way that I tend to think about frameworks is that they're more like a job aid. They're more like a learning tool that the team kind of uses to keep themself on track. But part of the thing is that those companies will reinvent the things they're using when things aren't working out.
text_ko: 그래서 저는 프레임워크(frameworks)를 오히려 업무 보조 도구(job aid)처럼 보는 편이에요. 팀이 스스로 길을 잃지 않게 도와주는 학습 도구 같은 거고요. 다만 잘 안 풀리면 그런 회사들은 쓰고 있던 것들을 다시 만들어 버리기도 해요.
text_zh: 所以我觉得吧，框架(framework)这个东西更像是一个工作辅助工具。就是团队用来让自己不跑偏的学习工具。但关键是，如果现有的东西不好用了，那些公司会重新发明他们在用的工具。
text_es: Y entonces, yo creo que la forma en que suelo ver los frameworks es más como una herramienta de apoyo en el trabajo. Son más como una herramienta de aprendizaje que el equipo usa para mantenerse enfocado. Pero lo que pasa es que esas empresas van a reinventar las cosas que están usando cuando no les están funcionando.
context: John explains his philosophy on how frameworks should be used in product development. Rather than treating frameworks as rigid processes that must be followed exactly, he views them as job aids - tools that help teams learn and stay focused. Successful companies adapt and modify frameworks when they're not working, rather than blindly following them regardless of results.
vocabulary_highlights: job aid, keep themself on track, reinvent the things

speaker: John Cutler
speaker_expertise: Team Building, Leadership Development, Product Management
text: And I talk about this a lot, this sort of I do believe there's sort of this fundamental attribution bias at play where people in these high performings don't acknowledge the amount that luck and inertia has been a part of what they're doing.
text_ko: 저는 이 얘기를 자주 하는데, 일종의 근본적 귀인 편향(fundamental attribution bias)이 있어서 성과가 높은 사람들일수록 자신들이 해온 일에 운과 관성이 얼마나 기여했는지를 잘 인정하지 않는다고 생각해요.
text_zh: 我经常说这个问题，我觉得这里面有个根本归因偏误(fundamental attribution bias)在起作用，就是那些业绩特别好的人，他们不愿意承认运气和惯性在他们成功中占了多大分量。
text_es: Y hablo mucho de esto, creo que hay como un sesgo de atribución fundamental (fundamental attribution bias) en juego donde la gente que tiene mucho éxito no reconoce hasta qué punto la suerte y la inercia han sido parte de lo que han logrado.
context: Lenny and John are discussing why advice from successful Silicon Valley companies doesn't always work for other organizations. John explains that there's a cognitive bias where successful companies and leaders attribute their success primarily to their skills and decisions, while underestimating the role of luck, timing, and favorable circumstances. This leads to advice that may not be applicable to companies in different situations.
vocabulary_highlights: fundamental attribution bias, at play, high performings
topics: Product Management, Decision Making, Learning & Growth

speaker: John Cutler
speaker_expertise: Team Building, Leadership Development, Product Management
text: And that the people in the big companies, or these not, these companies that believe that it's not the way that they can do that actually overestimate the kind of systemic drag in their organization and underestimate what can be possible.
text_ko: 대기업에 있는 사람들이나 '그건 우리가 못 해'라고 믿는 회사들은 조직의 시스템적 저항(systemic drag)을 과대평가하고 실제로 가능한 것들은 과소평가해요.
text_zh: 那些大公司的人，或者说那些认为这样做不可行的公司，其实都高估了自己组织内部的体系阻力(systemic drag)，低估了真正能做到的事情。
text_es: Y la gente de las empresas grandes, o bueno, estas empresas que creen que no es la forma en que pueden hacerlo, en realidad sobreestiman la inercia del sistema (systemic drag) que tienen en su organización y subestiman lo que realmente se puede lograr.
context: John continues explaining the attribution bias that affects how companies view their ability to change. While successful companies underestimate the role of luck in their success, struggling companies tend to overestimate the barriers holding them back (systemic drag) and underestimate what improvements are actually possible within their constraints.
vocabulary_highlights: systemic drag, what can be possible
topics: Product Management, Leadership & Management, Decision Making

speaker: John Cutler
speaker_expertise: Team Building, Leadership Development, Product Management
text: I think that what I realized over the course of these four years is that I wanted to pivot back to help put most of my energy into helping my own company. They're growing super fast, so the numbers are in the hundreds of everything or in the thousands of everything.
text_ko: 이 4년 동안 깨달은 건 제가 다시 제 회사 쪽으로 방향을 틀어(pivot back) 제 에너지 대부분을 그쪽에 쏟고 싶었다는 거예요. 회사가 엄청 빨리 커지고 있어서 거의 모든 수치가 수백 단위거나 많게는 수천 단위예요.
text_zh: 我觉得这四年下来我意识到，我想要转回去(pivot)，把大部分精力都投入到帮助自己的公司上。他们现在发展特别快，各项数据都是几百几千这个量级的。
text_es: Creo que lo que me di cuenta durante estos cuatro años es que quería cambiar de rumbo y enfocar la mayor parte de mi energía en ayudar a mi propia empresa. Están creciendo súper rápido, así que las cifras están en cientos de todo o en miles de todo.
context: John explains why he's leaving his role as Product Evangelist at Amplitude to join Toast. After four years of helping hundreds of different companies improve their product practices, he wants to focus his energy on helping one company - Toast - which is experiencing rapid growth and has multiple business lines beyond just their core point-of-sale business.
vocabulary_highlights: pivot back, super fast, in the hundreds of everything

speaker: John Mark Nickels
text: And so it's really just about becoming more aware and then taking responsibility for the influence that I have. So yeah, taking responsibility for my influence in the world.
text_ko: 결국엔 제 영향력을 더 인식하고 그 영향에 책임을 지는 거예요. 그러니까 제가 세상에 미치는 영향에 책임을 지는 거예요.
text_zh: 其实就是要更有自知之明，然后对自己的影响力负起责任来。对，就是要为自己在这个世界上产生的影响负责任。
text_es: Y entonces realmente se trata de ser más consciente y luego asumir la responsabilidad de la influencia que tengo. Sí, hacerme responsable de mi influencia en el mundo.
context: Lenny asks J.M. to define conscious leadership, a phrase that came up repeatedly when asking colleagues about him. J.M. explains that leadership is having influence in the world, which applies to everyone regardless of whether they're managers. The conscious part involves becoming more aware of your internal world, biases, and inherited belief systems, then taking responsibility for how you use that influence.
vocabulary_highlights: taking responsibility for, influence in the world

speaker: John Mark Nickels
text: What I kind of woke up to at one point was that as long as I was going out there looking for all that stuff to try to complete something inside of me that was missing, it's like I was a hungry ghost. It's like, it doesn't matter how many Michelin star meals and promotions and money and title and whatever. It's like it's never enough.
text_ko: 어느 순간 제가 깨달은 건, 내 안의 뭔가를 채우려고 바깥에서 이 모든 걸 찾아다니는 한 나는 배고픈 유령(hungry ghost) 같았다는 거예요. 아무리 미쉐린 스타 식사(Michelin-star meals)를 하고, 승진하고, 돈을 많이 벌고, 직함을 얻어도 결국엔 결코 충분하지 않더라고요.
text_zh: 我突然意识到，只要我还在外面拼命找各种东西来填补内心的空虚，就像个饿鬼一样。不管是米其林餐厅、升职加薪、头衔什么的，永远都填不满，永远觉得不够。
text_es: Lo que me di cuenta en un momento fue que mientras anduviera por ahí buscando todas esas cosas para tratar de llenar algo que me faltaba por dentro, era como ser un fantasma hambriento. O sea, no importa cuántas comidas de restaurantes con estrellas Michelin, ascensos, dinero, títulos o lo que sea. Es como que nunca es suficiente.
context: J.M. discusses how to handle stress and emotions in high-stakes meetings. He explains his realization about seeking external validation for self-worth. Instead of trying to force approval from leaders like Dara, he learned that looking for security, control, and approval from external sources creates an endless cycle of need - comparing it to being a "hungry ghost" that can never be satisfied.
vocabulary_highlights: woke up to, hungry ghost, never enough
topics: Leadership & Management, Work-Life Balance, Coaching & Development

speaker: John Mark Nickels
text: The more I focused on how I show up and optics and having a good deck and all this, the less I got promoted and then the more I dropped focusing all that. Because for my first few years of Uber, I was a senior PM and then I finally got my groove and started kind of moving through the product ladder.
text_ko: 제가 어떻게 보이는지, 겉보기 이미지(optics)나 좋은 데크(deck) 같은 것들에 더 신경 쓸수록 오히려 승진을 덜 받았어요. 그래서 그런 것들에 신경 쓰는 걸 점점 덜 하게 됐죠. 우버에서 처음 몇 년간은 시니어 PM(senior PM)이었는데, 드디어 감을 잡고 프로덕트 직급(product ladder)을 차근차근 올라가기 시작했어요.
text_zh: 我越是纠结怎么表现自己、怎么看起来专业、做个漂亮的PPT这些事儿，反而越升不了职。后来我就不太在意这些了，因为在Uber的头几年我就是个高级PM(senior PM)，直到后来找到感觉了，才开始在产品这条线上往上爬。
text_es: Mientras más me enfocaba en cómo me veía, en la imagen que proyectaba, en tener una presentación perfecta y todo eso, menos me ascendían. Pero cuando dejé de obsesionarme con esas cosas... Porque en mis primeros años en Uber, era senior PM y luego finalmente agarré el hilo y empecé a subir en la escalera de producto.
context: Lenny asks about managing high-stakes situations where career consequences feel real. J.M. shares a counterintuitive insight from his career progression at Uber - the more he focused on presentations, optics, and appearing successful, the less he actually got promoted. Only when he shifted focus away from how he was perceived and toward doing great work did he start advancing through the product management levels.
vocabulary_highlights: got my groove, moving through the product ladder

speaker: John Mark Nickels
text: And it's really about, I want to make a fucking awesome product, right? And it's like, whether people like me or think I'm a good PM or presenter, as long as I manifest a great product into the world that makes riders better off, drivers better off, cities better off, less congestion, all these things, that to me is the reward.
text_ko: 정말 중요한 건, 저는 진짜 끝내주는 제품을 만들고 싶어요. 사람들이 저를 좋아하든, 제가 좋은 프로덕트 매니저(PM)나 프레젠터(presenter)라고 생각하든 상관없이, 그 제품이 라이더(rider)와 드라이버(driver) 모두에게 도움이 되고 도시도 좋아지고 교통 혼잡(congestion)이 줄어드는 그런 멋진 제품을 세상에 내놓기만 하면, 그게 제게는 보람이에요.
text_zh: 说白了就是，我就想做出一个特别牛逼的产品，对吧？至于别人喜不喜欢我，觉得我是不是个好的产品经理(PM)或者演讲者，这些都无所谓，只要我能把一个真正棒的产品带到这个世界上，让乘客受益，让司机受益，让城市变得更好，减少拥堵，实现这些东西，对我来说就是最大的回报了。
text_es: Y realmente se trata de esto: quiero crear un producto que sea la hostia, ¿vale? Y es como, da igual si la gente me cae bien o piensa que soy buen PM o buen presentador, mientras logre materializar un gran producto que mejore la vida de los usuarios, que mejore la vida de los conductores, que mejore las ciudades, menos tráfico, todas estas cosas, para mí esa es la recompensa.
context: J.M. continues explaining his philosophy on focusing on work over optics. He describes how shifting from ego-driven concerns about personal perception to mission-driven focus on creating great products became more fulfilling and paradoxically more successful. By tapping into a larger purpose around transportation and mobility, he dropped the self-centered focus on presentation performance.
vocabulary_highlights: manifest a great product, better off

speaker: John Mark Nickels
text: And so step one is, am I working at a place and in a product area in which I have a tremendous amount of passion? Because for me, that is the fuel and the motivation that helps me break through to getting the strategy. That's the first step.
text_ko: 그래서 첫 번째로 확인할 건, 제가 일하는 회사와 맡고 있는 제품 분야에 정말 큰 열정이 있는지예요. 저한텐 그 열정이 바로 전략을 세우게 해주는 연료이자 동기예요. 그게 첫걸음이에요.
text_zh: 所以第一步就是，我现在工作的地方，还有我做的这个产品领域，是不是我真的特别有热情？因为对我来说，这个热情就是我的动力，能推动我突破瓶颈，找到正确的战略方向。这是最关键的第一步。
text_es: Y entonces el primer paso es: ¿estoy trabajando en un lugar y en un área de producto que realmente me apasiona? Porque para mí, esa es la gasolina y la motivación que me ayuda a romper barreras para llegar a la estrategia. Ese es el primer paso.
context: Lenny asks for advice on how to improve at strategy and vision, which colleagues identified as J.M.'s strengths. J.M. explains that there's no magic toolkit for strategy - the first essential step is finding genuine passion for your work area. He emphasizes that without deep passion for the mission, it would be difficult to develop breakthrough strategic thinking, using healthcare as an example of an important area he personally lacks passion for.
vocabulary_highlights: tremendous amount of passion, break through to getting the strategy

speaker: John Mark Nickels
text: Get clear on your objective function, and one way that I've gotten clear on it is trying to think about it from future me because five years from now, I'm not going to give a shit if I made the presentation slightly better, but I'm going to care a lot about what kind of relationship I have with my daughters.
text_ko: 목표 함수(objective function)를 명확히 하세요. 제가 그걸 명확히 한 방법 중 하나는 미래의 나 입장에서 생각해 보는 건데요, 5년 뒤에는 프레젠테이션을 조금 더 잘했는지 같은 건 별로 신경 안 쓸 테지만 딸들과 어떤 관계를 맺고 있을지는 훨씬 더 중요하게 생각할 거예요.
text_zh: 你得搞清楚自己真正的目标是什么，我自己想明白这个问题的方法就是站在未来的角度去思考——五年以后的我，根本不会在乎当时的演示做得好一点还是差一点，但我肯定会非常在意跟女儿们的关系怎么样。
text_es: Ten claro cuál es tu función objetivo, y una forma en que yo lo he logrado es tratando de pensarlo desde mi yo del futuro, porque dentro de cinco años me va a valer madre si hice la presentación un poquito mejor, pero sí me va a importar muchísimo qué tipo de relación tengo con mis hijas.
context: Lenny asks about keys to a successful and meaningful life. J.M. emphasizes the importance of being conscious about your life's objective function, referencing Clayton Christensen's insight about successful executives with failed personal lives. He suggests thinking from the perspective of your future self to clarify what truly matters - relationships with family will matter much more than marginal improvements to work presentations.
vocabulary_highlights: objective function, not going to give a shit, future me

speaker: John Mark Nickels
text: The one thing I'd encourage folks to do out of all of these we talked about is to see if you'd be willing to commit to breaking out of victim consciousness and mentality. And it's not to say there aren't victims in the world, there are real injustices and things happening, but most of us, I've experienced, I often can fall into the trap of living my life at the effect of, right?
text_ko: 제가 우리가 얘기한 것들 중에 한 가지만 권하고 싶은 건, 피해자 의식(victim consciousness)이나 피해자 마인드(victim mentality)에서 벗어나겠다고 스스로 약속해 보실 수 있는지 살펴보자는 거예요. 세상에 진짜 피해자가 있고 실제로 부당한 일들도 있는 건 맞아요. 다만 제 경험으로는 우리 대부분—저도 자주 그렇듯이—외부 영향에 끌려다니며 반응적으로 사는 함정에 빠지기 쉬워요.
text_zh: 在我们聊的这些当中，我最想鼓励大家做的一件事就是，看看你们愿不愿意下决心摆脱受害者心态(victim mentality)。我不是说这世界上没有受害者，确实存在不公和各种问题，但我们大多数人，包括我自己的经历，经常会掉进这样的陷阱——总觉得自己的生活被外界因素左右，对吧？
text_es: De todo lo que hemos charlado, lo único que realmente les recomendaría es que se animen a comprometerse a salir de esa mentalidad de víctima. Y no es que no haya víctimas reales en el mundo, claro que hay injusticias y cosas que pasan de verdad, pero la mayoría de nosotros, por mi experiencia, yo mismo muchas veces caigo en la trampa de vivir mi vida como si todo me pasara a mí, ¿no?
context: As the conversation winds down, J.M. shares what he considers the most important takeaway from their discussion. He encourages listeners to shift from victim consciousness - feeling like life is happening to them and they're at the effect of circumstances, other people, and external conditions - to taking responsibility for how they see and respond to the world, even while acknowledging that real injustices exist.
vocabulary_highlights: victim consciousness, living my life at the effect of

speaker: Jonathan Becker
text: The effect ultimately that we've seen from a human capital point of view is displacement. We have more people now than we've ever had, but the nature of the work that they do is more strategic. It's more about modeling, validation, asking the right questions, being focused around creative levers. And less so the like trench work of implementation and bid modifiers at the keyword level on Google search, and some of the really hardcore manual analysis we had to do.
text_ko: 인적 자본(human capital) 관점에서 보면 결국 나타난 효과는 역할의 재배치(displacement)이에요. 지금 인원은 예전보다 더 많지만, 하는 일의 성격이 훨씬 더 전략적이에요. 이제는 모델링(modeling)과 검증(validation), 올바른 질문을 던지는 것, 창의적 레버(creative levers)에 집중하는 비중이 커졌어요. 반면 구글 검색의 키워드 수준에서 입찰 조정(bid modifiers)을 일일이 손보는 일이나, 예전처럼 정말 수작업 분석(manual analysis)을 해야 했던 그런 실무 중심의 작업은 줄었어요.
text_zh: 从人力资源的角度来看，我们看到的最终效果其实是人员转型。现在我们的人比以前还多，但是他们干的活儿性质变了，更偏战略性了。更多的是做建模、验证，问对问题，专注在创意杠杆(creative levers)上。不像以前那样做苦力活儿，比如在谷歌搜索里调关键词的出价修饰符(bid modifiers)，还有那些特别费劲的手工分析工作。
text_es: Al final, lo que hemos visto desde el punto de vista del capital humano es un desplazamiento. Tenemos más gente ahora que nunca, pero el tipo de trabajo que hacen es más estratégico. Se trata más de modelado, validación, hacer las preguntas correctas, enfocarse en palancas creativas (creative levers). Y menos del trabajo pesado de implementación y modificadores de pujas (bid modifiers) a nivel de palabra clave en Google search, y algunos de los análisis manuales súper técnicos que teníamos que hacer antes.
context: Lenny asks Jonathan about how AI is impacting the performance marketing industry. Jonathan explains that AI has been influencing their industry for over a decade, as platforms like Google and Facebook have used AI to automate many manual tasks. He describes how this automation has changed the nature of work at his agency, shifting employees from manual implementation work to more strategic responsibilities.
vocabulary_highlights: trench work, bid modifiers, hardcore manual analysis

speaker: Jonathan Becker
text: On our creative group, we can come up with mockups, in literally, 1% of the time that it took. And so you still have to understand what questions to ask of the AI and be capable of iterating, but these rough drafts that you might show the artwork of to a client to say, 'Do we like this more or do we like this more?' That's AI generated. It's really interesting.
text_ko: 우리 크리에이티브 팀에서는 예전에 걸리던 시간의 문자 그대로 1% 만에 목업(mockups)을 만들어낼 수 있어요. 물론 인공지능(AI)에게 어떤 질문을 해야 할지 이해하고, 반복(iterate)해서 다듬을 수 있어야 해요. 그래도 클라이언트에게 '이게 더 나아요, 아니면 이게 더 나아요?' 하면서 아트워크(artwork) 초안(rough drafts)을 보여줄 수 있을 정도의 안들이 인공지능(AI)으로 생성된다는 건 정말 흥미로워요.
text_zh: 我们创意团队现在做原型(mockup)的速度，真的是比以前快了一百倍。当然你还是得知道怎么问AI问题，怎么不断调整，但是那些给客户看的初稿啊、设计图什么的，就是问他们"你觉得这个好还是那个好？"这些都是AI生成的。真的挺有意思的。
text_es: En nuestro equipo creativo, podemos crear bocetos (mockups) en literalmente el 1% del tiempo que nos tomaba antes. O sea, todavía tienes que saber qué preguntas hacerle a la IA y ser capaz de iterar, pero esos borradores que le podrías enseñar a un cliente para decirle '¿Te gusta más esto o te gusta más esto otro?' Eso lo genera la IA. Está súper interesante.
context: Jonathan continues explaining how AI tools are transforming creative work at his performance marketing agency. He describes how AI image generators like Dall-E and MidJourney allow his creative team to produce initial mockups and concept artwork dramatically faster than before. However, he emphasizes that human expertise is still needed to ask the right questions and iterate on the AI-generated outputs.
vocabulary_highlights: rough drafts, capable of iterating

speaker: Jonathan Becker
text: I always say to people that the first rule of performance marketing is not to forget about offline marketing and the classic marketing that works for organizations. In other words, direct mail can really work, email marketing works beautifully, SEO can really work. There's all of these wonderful things at your disposal. The real crash and burn scenarios that I've seen are these, not fly by night brands, but brands that figured out... Just like with Uber, I figured out this weird tie-in where I could make free money from their referral system.
text_ko: 저는 항상 사람들에게 성과 마케팅의 첫 번째 규칙은 오프라인 마케팅과 조직에 효과적인 클래식 마케팅을 잊지 않는 것이라고 말해요. 다시 말해, 다이렉트 메일(direct mail)도 정말 효과적일 수 있고, 이메일 마케팅(email marketing)도 아주 잘 작동해요. SEO도 정말 효과적이에요. 여러분이 활용할 수 있는 멋진 것들이 많아요. 제가 본 진짜 실패 사례는 단기 브랜드가 아니라, 우버(Uber)처럼 그들의 추천 시스템을 통해 무료로 돈을 벌 수 있는 기회를 찾아낸 브랜드들이에요.
text_zh: 我经常跟别人说，效果营销(performance marketing)的第一条铁律就是别忘了线下营销和那些对公司确实管用的传统营销手段。换句话说，直邮真的有效果，邮件营销效果特别好，SEO也确实能起作用。你手头有这么多好用的工具。我见过的那些真正翻车的案例是这样的，不是那些三天打鱼两天晒网的品牌，而是那些琢磨出了门道的品牌...就像Uber一样，我发现了一个奇怪的套路，可以从他们的推荐系统(referral system)里白赚钱。
text_es: Siempre les digo a la gente que la primera regla del marketing de resultados (performance marketing) es no olvidarse del marketing offline y del marketing clásico que funciona para las organizaciones. O sea, el correo directo puede funcionar de maravilla, el email marketing funciona bárbaro, el SEO puede dar muy buenos resultados. Tienes todas estas herramientas increíbles a tu disposición. Los verdaderos fracasos que he visto son estos: no marcas que aparecen de la noche a la mañana, sino marcas que descubrieron... Igual que con Uber, yo descubrí esta conexión rara donde podía generar dinero gratis con su sistema de referidos.
context: Lenny asks about the perception that paid growth can become addictive like a drug for companies. Jonathan addresses this concern by explaining his philosophy of marketing channel diversification. He warns against putting all marketing budget into a single performance marketing channel, comparing it to investing all your money in one stock. He emphasizes the importance of maintaining a mix of both online and offline marketing channels to avoid volatility.
vocabulary_highlights: at your disposal, crash and burn scenarios, fly by night brands, weird tie-in

speaker: Jonathan Becker
text: Sometimes people find shortcuts, hacks if you will, to scale rapidly because of one specific nuance of the Facebook ad platform, or something like that. And what they fail to see is that those loopholes come and go. And so if they scale massively and their entire business is predicated on the performance of this one loophole that they found, or investing everything in a single channel, and then the conditions change, they're not going to be very happy and the business will suffer dramatically.
text_ko: 사람들이 가끔 페이스북 광고 플랫폼(Facebook ad platform)의 어떤 사소한 특징 때문에 빠르게 확장할 수 있는 쇼트컷(shortcuts)이나 핵(hacks)을 찾아내요. 그런데 사람들이 놓치는 건 그런 허점(loopholes)이 언제든 생겼다 사라질 수 있다는 점이에요. 그래서 그 허점 하나의 퍼포먼스(performance)에 비즈니스 전체를 걸거나 한 채널(channel)에 모든 걸 투자해 대규모로 확장하면, 상황이 바뀔 때 엄청난 타격을 받고 비즈니스가 크게 흔들려요.
text_zh: 有时候大家会找到一些捷径，或者说是窍门吧，比如利用Facebook广告平台的某个特殊机制来快速做大规模。但他们没看到的是，这些漏洞都是来来去去的。如果他们疯狂扩张，整个生意都建立在发现的这一个漏洞上，或者把所有鸡蛋都放在一个渠道里，等到情况一变，他们就傻眼了，生意也会遭受重创。
text_es: A veces la gente encuentra atajos, trucos si quieres, para crecer rápidamente por algún detalle específico de la plataforma de anuncios de Facebook, o algo así. Y lo que no logran ver es que esas lagunas van y vienen. Entonces, si escalan masivamente y todo su negocio depende del rendimiento de esta laguna que encontraron, o si invierten todo en un solo canal, y luego las condiciones cambian, no van a estar nada contentos y el negocio va a sufrir tremendamente.
context: Jonathan continues his explanation about why over-reliance on performance marketing can be dangerous. He describes how some companies discover temporary advantages or 'loopholes' in advertising platforms that allow them to scale quickly and cheaply. However, he warns that these advantages are typically short-lived, and companies that build their entire business model around exploiting one specific platform feature will face serious problems when those conditions change.
vocabulary_highlights: hacks if you will, one specific nuance, loopholes come and go, predicated on
topics: Growth & Marketing, Strategy & Planning, Decision Making

speaker: Jonathan Becker
text: The antidote to that is to have resources dedicated to paid and essentially iterate upon the creative assets themselves based on the data that we see coming from ad sets and campaigns in various channels. And so what that means is that you have to experiment. You have to take a bit of a scientific approach, although it's a bit of an art and a bit of a science. You have to try and isolate variables, maintain similar conditions across targeting, and then determine which style and feature of an ad performs best at which stage of the funnel versus which audience.
text_ko: 그에 대한 해결책은 유료 마케팅에 전담 자원(인력·예산)을 배정해서, 여러 채널(channels)의 광고 세트(ad sets)와 캠페인(campaigns)에서 나오는 데이터를 바탕으로 크리에이티브 자산(creative assets)을 직접 지속적으로 테스트하고 개선하는 거예요. 즉, 실험을 해야 한다는 뜻이에요. 어느 정도는 예술적인 감각도 필요하지만 과학적인 접근법도 취해야 해요. 변수(variables)를 분리해 가면서 실험하고, 타깃팅(targeting)별로 조건을 비슷하게 유지한 뒤, 어떤 광고의 스타일이나 요소가 퍼널(funnel)의 어느 단계에서 어떤 오디언스(audience)에 대해 가장 잘 작동하는지 판단해야 해요.
text_zh: 解决这个问题的办法就是专门投入资源做付费推广，然后根据各个渠道的广告组合和推广活动(campaigns)反馈回来的数据，不断优化创意素材本身。这就意味着你得做各种测试，要用比较科学的方法来做，当然这个事儿既是门艺术也是门科学。你需要试着控制变量，在定向投放(targeting)上保持相似的条件，然后搞清楚哪种广告风格和特点在转化漏斗(funnel)的不同阶段、针对不同受众群体表现最好。
text_es: La solución es tener recursos dedicados a publicidad pagada y básicamente ir iterando los creativos basándote en los datos que ves de los conjuntos de anuncios (ad sets) y campañas en los diferentes canales. Esto significa que tienes que experimentar. Tienes que adoptar un enfoque medio científico, aunque también es un arte - tienes que tratar de aislar variables, mantener condiciones similares en la segmentación (targeting), y después determinar qué estilo y características de un anuncio funcionan mejor en cada etapa del embudo (funnel) según la audiencia.
context: Lenny asks Jonathan about the importance of creative testing in performance marketing. Jonathan explains that one major problem he sees is when brand teams create generic assets without understanding how paid channels work. He describes the solution: having dedicated resources for paid marketing that can systematically test and iterate on creative assets based on performance data, treating it as both an art and science.
vocabulary_highlights: antidote to that, iterate upon, isolate variables, stage of the funnel

speaker: Jonathan Becker
text: We had plenty of projects that we worked on that flatlined during that period. And so the sense that there was a period of time where this was easy or it worked on any project is not correct in my opinion. With that said, we see companies that are spending millions of dollars a month on performance marketing channels like Google and Meta still, despite all the ups and downs that they have faced and they do so profitably.
text_ko: 그 기간 동안 우리가 진행하던 프로젝트 중 상당수가 성과가 정체되거나 중단됐어요. 그래서 이게 쉬웠다거나 어떤 프로젝트에나 통했다는 인식은 제 생각에 옳지 않아요. 그렇긴 해도 구글과 메타 같은 퍼포먼스 마케팅(performance marketing) 채널에 월 수백만 달러를 여전히 지출하면서 여러 기복을 겪었음에도 불구하고 수익을 내는 회사들을 보고 있어요.
text_zh: 我们在那段时间有很多项目都没什么起色，基本上是停滞不前的状态。所以如果有人觉得那段时间很轻松，或者觉得随便做个项目都能成功，我觉得这种想法是不对的。话虽如此，我们确实看到有些公司尽管经历了各种起起伏伏，但每个月还是会在Google、Meta这些效果营销(performance marketing)渠道上砸几百万美金，而且还能赚钱。
text_es: Tuvimos un montón de proyectos en los que trabajamos que se quedaron planos durante esa época. Entonces la idea de que hubo un período donde esto era fácil o funcionaba con cualquier proyecto no es correcta desde mi punto de vista. Dicho esto, seguimos viendo empresas que están gastando millones de dólares al mes en canales de marketing de performance como Google y Meta, a pesar de todas las subidas y bajadas que han enfrentado, y lo hacen de manera rentable.
context: Lenny asks whether startups can still scale almost exclusively through performance marketing, referencing successful companies from the 2010s. Jonathan provides a balanced perspective, explaining that while successful unicorns did use performance marketing, not every company that used performance marketing succeeded. He clarifies that there was never a time when performance marketing was universally easy or guaranteed to work, even during the supposed 'golden era' of the 2010s.
vocabulary_highlights: flatlined during that period, despite all the ups and downs

speaker: Jonathan Lowenhar
speaker_expertise: Leadership Development, Executive Coaching, Product Management
text: What Magic Box argues, is that the best outcomes for early-stage startups don't happen that way. You're never for sale. In fact, you have seduced a buyer. They see the fantasy, they fall in love.
text_ko: 매직 박스(Magic Box)가 말하는 건 초기 단계 스타트업에게 가장 좋은 결과는 그런 방식으로 오지 않는다는 거예요. 스타트업은 결코 '판매 대상'이 아니에요. 사실은 오히려 구매자를 매혹시킨 거예요. 그들은 그 판타지를 보고 사랑에 빠져요.
text_zh: Magic Box的观点是，对于早期创业公司来说，最好的结果不是这么来的。你从来不是待价而沽，实际上，你是在撩买家。他们看到了美好的愿景，然后就心动了。
text_es: Lo que plantea Magic Box es que los mejores resultados para startups en etapa temprana no suceden así. Nunca estás en venta. De hecho, has seducido a un comprador. Ven la fantasía, se enamoran.
context: Lenny asks Jonathan about his Magic Box paradigm methodology for successfully selling startups. Jonathan is contrasting this approach with traditional M&A processes where companies put themselves up for sale and run a formal auction process. The Magic Box paradigm is a methodology that teaches founders to create acquisition opportunities by making buyers fall in love with a future vision rather than going through traditional sales processes.
