vocabulary_highlights: seduced a buyer, see the fantasy, fall in love

speaker: Jonathan Lowenhar
speaker_expertise: Leadership Development, Executive Coaching, Product Management
text: To be a founder is a state of being, it's an attitude. To be a CEO is a craft. The more founders who can accept that those are two separate things and they're both equally important to build an ascendant startup, the better all of us will be.
text_ko: 창업자(founder)는 어떤 정체성이자 태도예요. 반면 CEO(Chief Executive Officer)는 숙련이 필요한 역할이에요. 창업자들이 이 둘이 분명히 다른 것이라는 걸 받아들이고, 둘 다 성장하는 스타트업을 만들기 위해 똑같이 중요하다는 걸 인정할수록 우리 모두가 더 나아질 거예요.
text_zh: 创始人是一种状态，一种心态。而CEO是一门手艺活儿。越多创始人能够接受这是两码事，而且对于打造一个蒸蒸日上的初创公司来说都同样重要，那对我们大家都更有好处。
text_es: Ser fundador es una forma de ser, es una actitud. Ser CEO es un oficio que se aprende. Mientras más fundadores puedan aceptar que son dos cosas completamente distintas y que ambas son igual de importantes para construir una startup exitosa, mejor nos va a ir a todos.
context: Jonathan is wrapping up the conversation by sharing his core philosophy about the founder journey. He's making a critical distinction that many founders miss - being a founder (having the vision, courage, and drive to start something) is fundamentally different from being a CEO (learning the operational skills to run and scale a business). An ascendant startup is one that's rising or advancing successfully.
vocabulary_highlights: state of being, ascendant startup

speaker: Jonathan Lowenhar
speaker_expertise: Leadership Development, Executive Coaching, Product Management
text: Founder mode gets me angry. That article just got me hot. It really felt like an excuse. We were giving founders a permission to not learn the job. It's not manager mode is bad, it's the greatest CEOs know when to calibrate which one is needed.
text_ko: 창업자 모드(Founder mode) 얘기만 나오면 화가 나요. 그 기사를 보고 정말 열받았어요. 완전 변명 같았어요. 우리는 창업자들(founders)에게 일을 배우지 않아도 된다는 면죄부를 준 셈이었거든요. 매니저 모드(manager mode)가 나쁘다는 게 아니라, 최고의 CEO들(CEOs)은 언제 어떤 모드를 써야 할지, 어떻게 조절(calibrate)해야 할지 알고 있어요.
text_zh: 创始人模式这个说法真的让我很火大。那篇文章看得我直冒火。感觉就是在找借口嘛。我们这不是在给创始人开绿灯，让他们不用学怎么当老板吗。不是说管理者模式不好，而是最厉害的CEO都知道什么时候该用哪一套。
text_es: El "founder mode" me saca de quicio. Ese artículo me puso de malas. La verdad es que se sintió como una excusa barata. Les estábamos dando permiso a los fundadores para no aprender a hacer bien el trabajo. No es que el "manager mode" sea malo, es que los mejores CEOs saben cuándo calibrar cuál de los dos se necesita.
context: Lenny asks Jonathan about his thoughts on the popular 'founder mode' concept that had been circulating in the startup community. Founder mode refers to the idea that founders should stay deeply involved in details rather than delegating everything to managers. Jonathan is expressing his frustration with this concept because he believes it gives founders an excuse to avoid developing proper CEO skills and learning how to manage and scale organizations effectively.
vocabulary_highlights: got me hot, calibrate which one is needed

speaker: Jonathan Lowenhar
speaker_expertise: Leadership Development, Executive Coaching, Product Management
text: More companies die from suicide than homicide, and it's grim, but also if the two or three people in charge of the business can't get along, nothing else matters. It's all going to break apart.
text_ko: 더 많은 회사가 외부의 공격으로 망하기보다 내부 갈등 때문에 스스로 무너져요. 참 암울하죠. 그런데 회사를 이끄는 두세 사람이 사이가 안 좋으면 다른 건 아무 소용 없어요. 결국 다 무너져 버려요.
text_zh: 更多公司是死于内斗而不是被外人搞垮的，这听起来很残酷，但确实如此。如果公司那几个当家的合不来，其他什么都白搭，早晚得散摊子。
text_es: Más empresas se van a pique por problemas internos que por la competencia, y aunque suena duro, si las dos o tres personas que manejan el negocio no se pueden ni ver, no importa nada más. Todo se va a ir al carajo.
context: Jonathan is explaining common failure modes for startups, categorizing them into four main areas. He's discussing what he calls 'founder's function' - the critical need for founding team members to work well together. By 'suicide vs homicide,' he means companies more often fail due to internal dysfunction (suicide) rather than external competitive forces (homicide). This is one of his frameworks for understanding why startups fail.
vocabulary_highlights: die from suicide than homicide

speaker: Jonathan Lowenhar
speaker_expertise: Leadership Development, Executive Coaching, Product Management
text: If you keep doing what you're doing, you keep getting what you're getting. And for the ready, fire, aim folks who realize the weakness of that at scale, the way to counteract that, is to start with good planning.
text_ko: 계속 지금 하던 대로만 하면 지금 얻고 있는 것만 계속 얻게 돼요. 그리고 그 약점이 대규모(at scale)로 드러난다는 걸 아는 '준비-발사-조준(ready, fire, aim)' 방식의 사람들에게는 그걸 상쇄하는 방법이 바로 좋은 계획부터 시작하는 거예요.
text_zh: 如果你一直按老办法做事，结果肯定还是老样子。对于那些习惯"准备，开火，瞄准"这种做法的人，当你意识到这样搞大了会有问题时，最好的解决办法就是一开始就做好规划。
text_es: Si sigues haciendo lo mismo de siempre, vas a seguir obteniendo los mismos resultados. Y para los que actúan primero y piensan después (ready, fire, aim) y se dan cuenta de que esto no funciona a gran escala, la manera de solucionarlo es empezar con una buena planificación desde el principio.
context: Jonathan is discussing the 'ready, fire, aim' CEO type - one of his failure mode categories for founders who act impulsively without proper planning. He's explaining that while improvisational skills might help founders get their companies started, the same approach won't work for scaling the business. He's sharing advice from a former boss and explaining how founders can transition from reactive decision-making to more strategic planning.
vocabulary_highlights: ready, fire, aim folks, counteract that, at scale

speaker: Jonathan Lowenhar
speaker_expertise: Leadership Development, Executive Coaching, Product Management
text: I trust founder intuition. If the founder says this business is still going to work, or this co-founder is the wrong person, or yes, it's time to sell, I'm in. We're just here to support them.
text_ko: 저는 창업자의 직감(founder intuition)을 믿어요. 창업자가 ‘이 사업은 아직 잘될 거예요’, ‘이 공동창업자(co-founder)는 맞지 않아요’, 또는 ‘이제 팔 때예요’라고 하면 저는 함께할게요. 우리는 그저 그들을 지원하러 온 거예요.
text_zh: 我相信创始人的直觉。如果创始人说这个生意还能做下去，或者说这个联合创始人不合适，或者说是时候卖掉了，我都支持。我们就是来给他们撑腰的。
text_es: Confío en la intuición del fundador. Si el fundador dice que este negocio todavía va a funcionar, o que este socio no es la persona indicada, o que sí, ya es hora de vender, yo me apunto. Nosotros estamos aquí simplemente para apoyarlos.
context: Lenny mentions that one of Jonathan's clients said the biggest lesson learned was to trust his intuition more. Jonathan is explaining his philosophy about supporting founders through difficult existential decisions. He believes that when founders get quiet and listen to their inner voice - what he calls founder intuition - they usually know the right answer. His role is not to give directive advice but to help founders access and trust their own judgment.
vocabulary_highlights: founder intuition, I'm in

speaker: Jonathan Lowenhar
speaker_expertise: Leadership Development, Executive Coaching, Product Management
text: Early stage founders, and this is certainly more true for the first timers than the veterans, the first timers are like twenty-something year olds in a bar and they're being social for the first time in their lives, and anyone that makes eye contact with them is enough for them to say, I want to go on a date with you.
text_ko: 초기 창업자들(early stage founders)은, 특히 처음 창업하는 사람들(first-timers)에게서 더 그렇습니다. 처음 창업하는 사람들은 마치 술집에 처음 나온 이십대 초반들처럼 사람들과 어울리는 게 처음이라서, 누군가 눈을 마주치기만 해도 '저 사람과 데이트하고 싶다'고 생각해요.
text_zh: 早期创业者，特别是那些第一次创业的，比有经验的老手更容易这样——就像二十多岁的年轻人第一次去酒吧社交，谁跟他们对个眼神，他们就想"我要跟你约会"。
text_es: Los fundadores en etapas tempranas, y esto es mucho más cierto para los primerizos que para los veteranos, los primerizos son como veinteañeros en un bar que están socializando por primera vez en sus vidas, y cualquiera que los mire a los ojos les basta para decir "quiero salir contigo".
context: Lenny asks Jonathan about go-to-market strategy and where founders should focus their efforts. Jonathan is explaining the biggest mistake first-time founders make when defining their ideal customer profile (ICP). He's using a humorous analogy to describe how inexperienced founders often lack discrimination in choosing customers - they'll try to sell to anyone who shows interest rather than being selective about their target market.
vocabulary_highlights: first timers, makes eye contact with them

speaker: Jonny Miller
text: So I find this top down, bottom up distinction to be incredibly helpful. Most people when they try to calm down, they use tactical reframes or maybe mindfulness or maybe reframing the situation in a positive light. There's lots of different practices that people use which do have some effect. But in my experience, working with the physiology, using what's known as a bottom up approach, primarily using the breath, although there's also other approaches that you can use, it's just such a rapidly more effective way of shifting your state.
text_ko: 저는 탑다운(top-down)과 바텀업(bottom-up) 구분이 정말 큰 도움이 된다고 느껴요. 대부분 사람들은 진정하려고 할 때 전술적 리프레임(tactical reframes)을 쓰거나 마인드풀니스(mindfulness)를 하거나 상황을 긍정적으로 재해석하곤 해요. 이런 저런 방법들이 꽤 효과가 있긴 하죠. 하지만 제 경험으로는 생리적 상태(physiology)를 다루는, 즉 바텀업(bottom-up) 접근법을 쓰는 게 — 주로 호흡을 이용하는 것이긴 하지만 다른 방법들도 있긴 해요 — 훨씬 더 빠르고 효과적으로 상태를 바꾸는 방법이에요.
text_zh: 所以我觉得这个自上而下和自下而上的区别特别有用。大多数人想要冷静下来的时候，都会用一些策略性的重新定义，或者正念，或者把情况往好的方面想。大家用的方法挺多的，也确实有点效果。但根据我的经验，从生理层面入手，用所谓的自下而上(bottom up)的方法，主要是通过呼吸，当然也有其他方法可以用，这种方式调整状态要快得多，效果也好得多。
text_es: Entonces esta distinción entre top down y bottom up me parece increíblemente útil. La mayoría de la gente, cuando trata de calmarse, usa replanteamientos tácticos o tal vez mindfulness o quizás reformular la situación de manera positiva. Hay un montón de prácticas diferentes que la gente usa y que sí tienen cierto efecto. Pero por mi experiencia, trabajar con la fisiología, usando lo que se conoce como enfoque bottom up, principalmente usando la respiración, aunque también hay otros enfoques que puedes usar, es una manera muchísimo más efectiva de cambiar tu estado.
context: Lenny asks Jonny about his general method for helping people become less nervous and anxious. Jonny explains the difference between top-down approaches (trying to calm yourself through thoughts and mental reframes) versus bottom-up approaches (changing your physical state first, primarily through breathing). He argues that bottom-up methods are much more effective for rapidly shifting from anxious to calm states.
vocabulary_highlights: tactical reframes, bottom up approach, rapidly more effective, shifting your state

speaker: Jonny Miller
text: And to give a little bit of context and maybe some science as well, we have what's known as afferent and efferent neurons going up and down our body, and there's four times more afferent neurons going from the body to the brain as from the brain to the body. So you can almost imagine there's a super highway of traffic of information going up to the brain and four times less going from the brain to the body.
text_ko: 조금 맥락과 과학적 설명을 덧붙이자면요, 우리 몸에는 몸에서 뇌로 올라가는 구심성 신경(afferent neurons)과 뇌에서 몸으로 내려가는 원심성 신경(efferent neurons)이 있어요. 그런데 몸에서 뇌로 가는 구심성 신경의 수가 뇌에서 몸으로 가는 신경보다 네 배나 많아요. 그래서 정보를 실어 나르는 통로가 뇌 쪽으로는 거대한 고속도로처럼 북적거리고, 뇌에서 몸으로 가는 쪽은 그보다 네 배쯤 더 적다고 생각하시면 돼요.
text_zh: 我来给大家解释一下背景，也从科学角度说说这个问题。我们身体里有传入神经元(afferent neurons)和传出神经元(efferent neurons)，负责上下传递信息。有意思的是，从身体传到大脑的传入神经元，比从大脑传到身体的传出神经元多四倍。你可以想象一下，就像有一条信息高速公路直通大脑，车流量超大，而从大脑往下走的那条路，车流量只有四分之一。
text_es: Y para dar un poco de contexto y tal vez algo de ciencia también, tenemos lo que se conoce como neuronas aferentes y eferentes que van de arriba a abajo en nuestro cuerpo, y hay cuatro veces más neuronas aferentes que van del cuerpo al cerebro que del cerebro al cuerpo. Entonces te puedes imaginar que hay como una superautopista de tráfico de información subiendo al cerebro y cuatro veces menos bajando del cerebro al cuerpo.
context: Jonny is explaining the scientific basis for why bottom-up approaches (focusing on the body first) are more effective than top-down approaches (trying to calm yourself through thoughts). He describes the neurological pathway system where afferent neurons carry signals from body to brain, while efferent neurons carry signals from brain to body. The key insight is that there are four times more neurons sending information from body to brain than the reverse.
vocabulary_highlights: afferent and efferent neurons, super highway of traffic

speaker: Jonny Miller
text: I have this idea that I call the feather brick dump truck phenomenon, and basically what that means is when we are showing early signs of burnout, our body will give us feedback usually in subtle ways in the beginning. So the feather might be waking up in the morning and feeling a little bit tired, maybe a little bit exhausted. The brick, maybe you ignore that or you don't notice it, and then three or four weeks later, you have a fight with someone or an argument, or you just feel frustrated and terrible and you lose your cool. And then maybe the dump truck is a month later, or even a year later, there's a full-blown health crisis, or you develop type two diabetes or there's a whole range of things, or maybe you get fired.
text_ko: 저는 '깃털-벽돌-덤프트럭 현상(feather brick dump truck phenomenon)'이라고 부르는 생각이 하나 있어요. 기본적으로 이 말은 초기에 번아웃(burnout)의 징후가 보일 때 우리 몸이 보통 처음에는 미묘한 방식으로 신호를 준다는 뜻이에요. 깃털 단계는 아침에 일어났을 때 평소보다 좀 피곤하다거나 약간 지친 느낌이 드는 정도예요. 벽돌 단계는 그걸 무시하거나 잘 알아차리지 못하는 단계고, 그러다 3~4주 뒤에 누군가와 말다툼이 생기거나, 그냥 짜증나고 기분이 엉망이 돼 감정 조절을 못하게 되는 거예요. 그리고 덤프트럭 단계는 한 달 뒤일 수도 있고 심지어 1년 뒤일 수도 있는데, 심각한 건강 문제로 이어지거나 제2형 당뇨병(type 2 diabetes)이 생기거나, 아니면 결국 해고되는 등 다양한 심각한 결과가 올 수 있어요.
text_zh: 我有个理论叫"羽毛砖头翻斗车现象(feather brick dump truck phenomenon)"，简单说就是当我们开始出现职业倦怠(burnout)的苗头时，身体会给我们反馈，通常一开始都是很微妙的信号。比如羽毛阶段，就是早上起床感觉有点累，有点没精神。到了砖头阶段，可能你忽视了这些信号或者没注意到，三四个星期后，你跟别人吵架起冲突，或者就是觉得特别烦躁难受，情绪失控。然后翻斗车阶段可能是一个月后，甚至一年后，就是全面的健康危机爆发，或者得了二型糖尿病，或者其他各种问题，也可能直接被炒鱿鱼。
text_es: Tengo esta idea que llamo el fenómeno de la pluma, el ladrillo y el camión de volteo, y básicamente lo que significa es que cuando empezamos a mostrar las primeras señales de agotamiento laboral (burnout), nuestro cuerpo nos manda señales, normalmente de manera sutil al principio. Entonces la pluma podría ser despertarte por la mañana y sentirte un poco cansado, tal vez algo agotado. El ladrillo, a lo mejor ignoras eso o no te das cuenta, y luego tres o cuatro semanas después, tienes una pelea con alguien o una discusión, o simplemente te sientes frustrado y fatal y pierdes los estribos. Y luego tal vez el camión de volteo es un mes después, o incluso un año después, hay una crisis de salud en toda regla, o desarrollas diabetes tipo dos o hay toda una gama de cosas, o a lo mejor te corren del trabajo.
context: Jonny is explaining his framework for understanding burnout progression - the 'feather brick dump truck phenomenon.' This concept describes how burnout warning signs escalate from subtle early symptoms (feather) to more serious problems (brick) to major crises (dump truck). He emphasizes the importance of catching and addressing burnout at the earliest 'feather' stage rather than waiting until it becomes a major life disruption.
vocabulary_highlights: feather brick dump truck phenomenon, full-blown health crisis, lose your cool

speaker: Jonny Miller
text: What I've seen with some of my founder clients and in the research that we did where we interviewed 260 leaders, what can often happen is that emotional debt will increase and increase and increase until it gets to a point where we are well outside what's known as a window of tolerance. And at that point there's like a crash. It's almost like the fuse switch blows and there's exhaustion. Maybe there's complete inability to get up off the couch.
text_ko: 제가 몇몇 창업자 고객들과 일하면서, 그리고 저희가 260명의 리더를 인터뷰한 연구에서 본 건, 감정적 빚(emotional debt)이 점점 쌓여서 결국 '견딜 수 있는 범위(window of tolerance)'를 완전히 벗어날 때까지 계속 늘어날 수 있다는 거예요. 그 지점에 이르면 거의 크래시(crash)가 나요. 퓨즈가 끊어지듯 스위치가 나가면서 완전히 탈진하고, 소파에서 일어나지 못할 정도가 되기도 해요.
text_zh: 我观察到的情况是这样的，不管是我服务的那些创始人客户，还是我们调研访谈的260位领导者，经常会出现这种现象：情感债务(emotional debt)会不断积累，越堆越多，直到超出了我们所说的"承受窗口"(window of tolerance)的范围。到了那个临界点就会崩盘，就像保险丝烧断了一样，人就彻底累垮了。可能会出现那种完全起不来床、躺在沙发上动不了的状态。
text_es: Lo que he visto con algunos de mis clientes fundadores y en la investigación que hicimos donde entrevistamos a 260 líderes, es que muchas veces pasa que la deuda emocional (emotional debt) va subiendo y subiendo hasta llegar a un punto donde ya estamos muy fuera de lo que se conoce como la ventana de tolerancia (window of tolerance). Y ahí es cuando viene el bajón fuerte. Es casi como si se fundiera el fusible y llega el agotamiento total. A lo mejor ni siquiera puedes levantarte del sofá.
context: Lenny asks Jonny how someone can notice they're building emotional debt and how to start releasing it. Jonny explains his concept of 'emotional debt' - the accumulated stress that builds up in the nervous system when we don't complete natural stress-recovery cycles. He describes how this debt accumulates until people reach their 'window of tolerance' limit, leading to crashes and exhaustion, particularly common among high-achieving founders and leaders.
vocabulary_highlights: emotional debt, window of tolerance, fuse switch blows

speaker: Jonny Miller
text: I like to recommend both a morning practice, particularly to build the muscle of just doing it and getting used to it. So maybe five minutes in the morning before you start work, before breakfast, something like that. And then you are more likely to remember that you have access to that in the moment because usually the challenge is that when someone is in that flustered state, remembering to do the practice is often the last thing that comes to mind.
text_ko: 저는 아침에 하는 연습도 같이 권해요. 특히 그냥 해버리는 실행 근육을 기르고 익숙해지기 위해서요. 예를 들어 출근하기 전이나 아침식사 전에 5분 정도 해보세요. 그러면 실제로 그 순간에 그걸 사용할 수 있다는 걸 더 잘 기억하게 돼요. 보통 문제는 누군가 정신없이 바쁠 때 연습을 해야 한다는 걸 떠올리는 게 가장 마지막이라는 점이에요.
text_zh: 我建议大家养成早上练习的习惯，主要是为了培养这个习惯，让自己适应这个过程。比如说早上工作前，或者吃早饭前，花个五分钟练习一下。这样的话，当你真正需要的时候，你更容易想起来自己有这个工具可以用。因为通常情况下，当一个人已经焦头烂额的时候，最不容易想起来的就是要去做这些练习。
text_es: Me gusta recomendar que lo hagas tanto en la mañana, sobre todo para crear el hábito de simplemente hacerlo y acostumbrarte. Entonces tal vez cinco minutos en la mañana antes de empezar a trabajar, antes del desayuno, algo así. Y entonces es más probable que te acuerdes de que tienes esa herramienta disponible justo cuando la necesitas, porque normalmente el problema es que cuando alguien está en ese estado de estrés y agobio, acordarse de hacer la práctica suele ser lo último que se le ocurre.
context: Lenny asks whether breathing exercises should be used only in the moment when needed or practiced regularly to build the skill. Jonny explains his recommendation for both regular practice and in-the-moment application. He emphasizes that consistent morning practice helps build the habit so people can more easily remember to use these techniques when they actually need them most - during stressful situations.
vocabulary_highlights: build the muscle, flustered state, last thing that comes to mind

speaker: Jonny Miller
text: And there's a quote from Kevin Kelly that I interviewed recently, and he said, 'If you have a great work ethic that needs to be matched with a great rest ethic.' And I think that kind of piece of actually training our capacity to downshift after stress is just completely missing from most people's playbooks.
text_ko: 제가 최근에 인터뷰한 케빈 켈리 말 중에 이런 게 있어요. "일에 대한 강한 근면성(work ethic)이 있다면 그에 상응하는 충분한 쉼에 대한 태도(rest ethic)가 필요하다." 그리고 저는 사실 스트레스가 지나간 뒤 속도를 낮추는 능력(downshift)을 훈련하는 부분이 대부분 사람들의 플레이북(playbook)에는 거의 빠져 있다고 생각해요.
text_zh: 我最近采访了凯文·凯利，他说了一句话特别有道理："如果你有很强的工作态度，那也得有同样强的休息态度。"我觉得他说得太对了，就是说怎么在压力过后让自己真正放松下来，这个能力大部分人根本就不会，也没人教过。
text_es: Y hay una cita de Kevin Kelly que entrevisté hace poco, y dijo: "Si tienes una gran ética de trabajo, eso tiene que ir acompañado de una gran ética de descanso." Y creo que esa parte de entrenar nuestra capacidad para bajar el ritmo después del estrés simplemente no está en el manual de la mayoría de la gente.
context: Jonny is discussing NSDR (Non-Sleep Deep Rest) practices and why they're valuable for high-performing individuals who struggle to naturally downshift from work mode. He shares a quote from Kevin Kelly about balancing work ethic with 'rest ethic' - the intentional practice of training your nervous system's ability to transition from high-stress 'go mode' to relaxation and recovery.
vocabulary_highlights: great rest ethic, capacity to downshift, missing from most people's playbooks

speaker: Josh Miller
speaker_expertise: User Experience, Product Management, Team Building
text: We want people that show up to our company with some fire in their belly, something that they are out to do. And for each person it's a little bit different. For some people it may be UI Craft details. For other people, it may be achieving double the performance with a quarter of the engineering headcount. Everyone has something, but they show up with this heartfelt intensity.
text_ko: 우리는 우리 회사에 들어올 사람들이 가슴 속에 불꽃 같은 열정, 뭔가 해내고자 하는 목표를 가지고 있기를 원해요. 사람마다 그게 조금씩 달라요. 어떤 사람에게는 UI 디테일(UI Craft)이 그럴 수 있고, 어떤 사람에게는 엔지니어링 인력수(engineering headcount)의 4분의 1로 성능을 두 배로 끌어올리는 것이 그럴 수 있어요. 모두 각자 그런 게 하나씩 있고, 그런 진심에서 우러나는 강한 열정을 안고 와요.
text_zh: 我们希望招到那种有冲劲儿、有想法的人，来了就想干点什么事儿的。每个人的点不一样，有些人可能特别在意UI设计的细节，有些人可能想用四分之一的工程师人手做出双倍的性能。反正每个人都有自己的那个劲儿，但都是带着那种发自内心的热情来的。
text_es: Buscamos gente que llegue a nuestra empresa con ganas de comerse el mundo, con algo que realmente quieren lograr. Y para cada persona es algo distinto. Para algunos puede ser perfeccionar cada detalle del UI. Para otros, puede ser lograr el doble de rendimiento con la cuarta parte del equipo de ingenieros. Cada quien tiene su cosa, pero llegan con esa intensidad que se siente de verdad, que les sale del corazón.
context: Lenny asks Josh about The Browser Company's hiring philosophy and what makes their team culture unique. Josh explains their core company value of hiring people with 'heartfelt intensity' - meaning they want team members who arrive with genuine passion and something specific they want to prove or accomplish, whether that's perfecting UI details or optimizing engineering performance.
vocabulary_highlights: fire in their belly, heartfelt intensity

speaker: Josh Miller
speaker_expertise: User Experience, Product Management, Team Building
text: What we do at The Browser Company is we talk about optimizing feelings. How do we want to make someone feel on the other end of our software? Do we want to make them feel joy? Do we want to make them feel fast? Do we want to make them feel organized? Do we want to make them feel focused? What is it the feeling we are trying to evoke in whatever we're doing on a specific project, or a specific feature, or a specific piece of storytelling content?
text_ko: 저희 The Browser Company에서는 감정 최적화(optimizing feelings)에 대해 이야기해요. 우리 소프트웨어를 사용하는 사람들에게 어떤 기분을 느끼게 하고 싶을까요? 기쁨을 느끼게 하고 싶나요? 빠르다고 느끼게 하고 싶나요? 정돈된 느낌을 주고 싶나요? 집중할 수 있게 하고 싶나요? 특정 프로젝트나 특정 기능, 혹은 한 편의 스토리텔링 콘텐츠에서 우리가 불러일으키려는 감정이 무엇인지 묻는 거예요.
text_zh: 我们Browser Company做的事情就是，我们会讲怎么去优化用户的感受。就是说，我们希望用我们软件的人能有什么样的感觉？我们是想让他们感到开心吗？还是想让他们觉得很快很流畅？或者是让他们觉得井井有条？还是让他们觉得很专注？就是说，不管我们在做某个具体项目，还是某个功能，或者某个内容的时候，我们到底想要唤起用户什么样的感觉？
text_es: En The Browser Company lo que hacemos es hablar de optimizar emociones. ¿Cómo queremos que se sienta la persona que está del otro lado usando nuestro software? ¿Queremos que sienta alegría? ¿Queremos que se sienta ágil? ¿Queremos que se sienta organizada? ¿Queremos que se sienta enfocada? ¿Cuál es esa emoción que tratamos de despertar en lo que sea que estemos haciendo - ya sea en un proyecto específico, una funcionalidad específica, o un contenido específico para contar nuestra historia?
context: Lenny asks Josh about his product building philosophy being a reaction to traditional Silicon Valley approaches. Josh explains that while most tech companies obsess over metrics and graphs, The Browser Company focuses on 'optimizing feelings' - deliberately considering what emotions they want to evoke in users through their software, whether it's joy, speed, organization, or focus.
vocabulary_highlights: optimizing feelings, evoke

speaker: Josh Miller
speaker_expertise: User Experience, Product Management, Team Building
text: I think sometimes we just forget that whoever your buyer is, or whatever your business objective, at the end of the day we're a bunch of people in a bunch of rooms at the other side of these screens. And just thinking about that person, it could be a buyer, it could be a customer.
text_ko: 가끔은 우리가 누가 당신의 구매자든, 사업 목표가 뭐든 결국 이 화면 저편에는 여러 방에 앉아 있는 사람들일 뿐이라는 걸 잊곤 해요. 그 사람을 그냥 한 사람으로 생각해 보면, 구매자일 수도 있고 고객일 수도 있어요.
text_zh: 我觉得有时候我们会忘记，不管你的买家是谁，不管你的商业目标是什么，说到底屏幕另一边坐在那些房间里的都是活生生的人。想想那个人，可能是买家，也可能是客户。
text_es: Creo que a veces se nos olvida que no importa quién sea tu comprador o cuál sea tu objetivo de negocio, al final del día somos un montón de personas en un montón de oficinas del otro lado de estas pantallas. Y hay que pensar en esa persona, puede ser un comprador, puede ser un cliente.
context: Lenny challenges Josh on how to operationalize the 'optimize for feelings' approach when companies still need to hit business goals and metrics. Josh responds by emphasizing that regardless of whether you're building consumer or enterprise software, there are real humans behind every transaction who experience emotions, and considering those human feelings often aligns well with business metrics.
vocabulary_highlights: at the end of the day

speaker: Josh Miller
speaker_expertise: User Experience, Product Management, Team Building
text: If you have a team that has heartfelt intensity and is there for a purpose and something to prove, you give them a very exciting, ambitious product and get out of their way and they will do remarkable work.
text_ko: 진심에서 우러나는 강한 열정과 분명한 목적, 그리고 보여주고자 하는 의지가 있는 팀이라면, 아주 흥미롭고 야심찬 제품을 맡겨주고 간섭하지 않으면 놀라운 일을 해낼 거예요.
text_zh: 如果你的团队有那种发自内心的干劲，有明确的目标和想证明自己的决心，你就给他们一个很有挑战性、很有野心的产品，然后别管太多，他们肯定能做出很牛的成果。
text_es: Si tienes un equipo que realmente le pone el corazón, que está ahí por una misión y con ganas de demostrar de qué es capaz, les das un producto emocionante y ambicioso, te quitas de en medio, y van a hacer un trabajo increíble.
context: Lenny asks Josh about The Browser Company's ability to ship quickly and meaningfully, referencing feedback from Scott Belsky. Josh explains their core hiring philosophy in more detail, emphasizing that when you hire people with genuine passion and intrinsic motivation ('heartfelt intensity'), the key to remarkable work is simply giving them ambitious challenges and removing obstacles from their path.
vocabulary_highlights: get out of their way, remarkable work

speaker: Josh Miller
speaker_expertise: User Experience, Product Management, Team Building
text: Our second value is assume you don't know. Assume you don't know. And the value 'assume you don't know' is, even if you're a subject matter expert. We have someone in our company that literally built the first version of Chrome and ran it for 16 years. But he more than anyone embodies this beginner's mind of, 'I have no idea how this should work or what will happen.'
text_ko: 우리의 두 번째 가치는 '모른다고 가정하기'예요. 모른다고 가정해요. 이 '모른다고 가정하기'라는 가치는 설령 당신이 주제 전문가(subject matter expert)라도 똑같이 적용돼요. 우리 회사에는 실제로 크롬(Chrome) 최초 버전을 만들고 16년 동안 운영했던 사람이 있어요. 그런데 그 사람은 누구보다도 '어떻게 작동해야 할지, 무슨 일이 일어날지 전혀 모른다'는 초심자 마인드(beginner's mind)를 몸에 지니고 있어요.
text_zh: 我们的第二个价值观是假设你什么都不懂。就是假设你什么都不懂。这个"假设你什么都不懂"的价值观，哪怕你是某个领域的专家也要这样。我们公司有个人，他亲手打造了Chrome的第一版，而且管了16年。但就是他，比谁都体现了这种初学者心态(beginner's mind)——"我压根不知道这玩意儿该怎么运作，也不知道会发生什么。"
text_es: Nuestro segundo valor es asumir que no sabes. Asumir que no sabes. Y este valor de "asumir que no sabes" significa que, incluso si eres un experto en el tema. Tenemos a alguien en nuestra empresa que literalmente construyó la primera versión de Chrome y la dirigió durante 16 años. Pero él más que nadie encarna esta mentalidad de principiante de "no tengo ni idea de cómo debería funcionar esto o qué va a pasar."
context: Lenny asks Josh to elaborate on The Browser Company's values and how they contribute to fast shipping. Josh explains their second core value 'assume you don't know,' which promotes a beginner's mindset even among experts. He uses the example of their team member who created Chrome but still approaches new problems with fresh perspective and curiosity.
vocabulary_highlights: assume you don't know, embodies, beginner's mind

speaker: Josh Miller
speaker_expertise: User Experience, Product Management, Team Building
text: What we say is, we want people that show up to our company with some fire in their belly, something that they are out to do. And for each person it's a little bit different. For some people it may be UI Craft details, for other people it may be achieving double the performance with a quarter of the engineering head count.
text_ko: 저희가 말하는 건, 뭔가 해내겠다는 불타는 열정을 가지고 우리 회사에 오는 사람들을 원해요. 사람마다 그 목적은 조금씩 달라요. 어떤 사람에게는 UI 디테일(UI Craft)이 중요할 수 있고, 또 다른 사람에게는 엔지니어 수(engineering head count)의 1/4로 성능을 두 배로 올리는 일이 될 수도 있어요.
text_zh: 我们的想法是这样的，我们希望来公司的人都有那种干劲儿，都有自己想要做成的事情。每个人的追求不太一样，有些人可能就是想把UI细节打磨到极致，有些人可能想用四分之一的工程师人数做出双倍的性能表现。
text_es: Lo que nosotros decimos es que queremos gente que llegue a nuestra empresa con ganas de comerse el mundo, con algo que realmente quieren lograr. Y para cada persona es un poco diferente. Para algunos puede ser los detalles del diseño de interfaz (UI craft), para otros puede ser lograr el doble de rendimiento con la cuarta parte del equipo de ingeniería.
context: Lenny asks Josh about what enables The Browser Company to ship so quickly and effectively, referencing Scott Belsky's observation about their execution speed. Josh explains their hiring philosophy, emphasizing they look for people with 'heartfelt intensity' - genuine passion and drive to excel in their particular area, whether that's design details or engineering optimization.
vocabulary_highlights: fire in their belly, out to do, head count

speaker: Judd Antin
speaker_expertise: User Experience, Product Strategy, Team Building
text: But you got to take the average PM who lives in that land, all day, every day, and what they do is not in the Venn. I think those are people who are also performing customer centricity and performing user-centeredness a lot, when they're really not interested. And so this is not about researcher. This takes two sides. Fixing this broken system takes everyone, researchers, PMs, designers, everyone at a company, but also the way that organization is structured, and integrating itself in a different way. Everybody's got to come to the table.
text_ko: 근데 평균적인 PM(프로덕트 매니저)은 그런 영역에서 하루 종일 일하고, 그들이 하는 일은 벤 다이어그램(Venn diagram)의 겹치지 않는 부분에 있어요. 겉으로는 고객 중심성(customer centricity)이나 사용자 중심성(user-centeredness)을 많이 실천하는 것처럼 보이지만, 사실은 별로 관심이 없을 때가 많아요. 이건 리서처(researcher)만의 문제가 아니에요. 이 깨진 시스템을 고치려면 양쪽의 노력이 필요하고, 리서처와 PM, 디자이너(designer), 회사의 모든 사람이 참여해야 해요. 조직 구조도 달라져야 하고, 서로 다른 방식으로 통합되어야 해요. 결국 모두가 함께 나와서 참여해야 해요.
text_zh: 但你得看看那些天天泡在这个圈子里的普通PM(产品经理)，他们做的事情其实根本不在这个交集里。我觉得这些人也在装模作样地搞什么以客户为中心、以用户为中心那一套，但其实他们压根就不感兴趣。所以这不光是研究员的问题，这事儿得两方面一起来。要想修复这套坏掉的系统，需要所有人一起努力——研究员、PM、设计师，公司里的每个人都得参与，而且整个组织架构也得调整，用不同的方式整合在一起。大家都得坐到谈判桌前。
text_es: Pero hay que considerar al PM promedio que vive en ese mundo todo el día, todos los días, y lo que hace no está en ese diagrama de Venn. Creo que esa gente también anda diciendo que se enfoca en el cliente y que pone al usuario primero, pero en realidad no les interesa para nada. Y esto no es solo cosa del investigador. Esto tiene dos caras. Arreglar este sistema roto requiere que todos se involucren - investigadores, PMs, diseñadores, toda la empresa - pero también cambiar la estructura organizacional e integrar todo de manera diferente. Todos tienen que poner de su parte.
context: Lenny asks Judd about user-centered performance and what advice he'd give to PMs who might recognize themselves in this pattern. Judd explains that while researchers need to be more business-focused, the problem exists on both sides - many product managers also engage in performative customer-centricity without genuine interest in learning. He emphasizes that fixing the broken research system requires collaboration from all roles, not just researchers changing their approach.
vocabulary_highlights: not in the Venn, performing customer centricity, come to the table
topics: Product Management, Leadership & Management, Communication Skills

speaker: Judd Antin
speaker_expertise: User Experience, Product Strategy, Team Building
text: User-centered performance refers to customer obsession or user-centered practice that is symbolic rather than focused on learning. It's hugely common, I would argue. It's work we do to signal to each other how customer obsessed we are, not because we want to make a different decision. If your listeners are like, 'I don't do that.' I'm like, 'Think about it for a second. This is extremely common.' Every time a PM comes to a researcher at the end of a product process and says, 'Can you just run a quick user study just to validate our assumptions,' that's user-centered performance. It's too late to matter. We got to ship it. What they want is to check the box.
text_ko: 사용자 중심 성과(user-centered performance)는 고객에 대한 집착이나 사용자 중심의 관행을 의미하는데, 학습에 집중하기보다는 상징적인 경우가 많아요. 사실 이건 굉장히 흔한 현상이라고 생각해요. 우리가 서로에게 고객에 대한 집착이 얼마나 강한지를 보여주기 위해 하는 일이지, 다른 결정을 내리기 위해서가 아니거든요. 만약 여러분이 '나는 그런 거 안 해요.'라고 생각한다면, 잠깐 생각해보세요. 이건 정말 흔한 일이에요. 제품 과정이 끝날 무렵에 PM이 연구자에게 와서 '우리의 가정을 검증하기 위해 간단한 사용자 조사를 해줄 수 있어요?'라고 말하는 경우가 바로 사용자 중심 성과예요. 그때는 이미 늦었고, 우리는 제품을 출시해야 하니까요. 그들이 원하는 건 체크박스를 채우는 거예요.
text_zh: 以用户为中心的表演(user-centered performance)指的是那种象征性的客户至上或以用户为中心的做法，而不是真正专注于学习。我觉得这种情况特别普遍。我们做这些工作是为了向彼此展示我们有多重视客户，而不是因为我们真的想做出不同的决策。如果你们听众觉得"我不会这样做"，我想说"仔细想想，这真的非常常见。"每次产品经理在产品流程快结束的时候跑去找研究员说"你能不能快速做个用户研究，验证一下我们的假设"，这就是以用户为中心的表演。这时候已经太晚了，起不了什么作用。产品必须得上线了。他们要的只是走个过场。
text_es: El rendimiento centrado en el usuario se refiere a esa obsesión por el cliente o esas prácticas que dicen ser centradas en el usuario pero que en realidad son más simbólicas que enfocadas en aprender de verdad. Yo diría que es súper común. Es trabajo que hacemos para demostrarles a los demás lo obsesionados que estamos con el cliente, no porque realmente queramos tomar una decisión diferente. Si los que me escuchan piensan "yo no hago eso", les digo "piénsenlo un segundo. Esto es extremadamente común". Cada vez que un PM se acerca a un investigador al final del proceso de producto y le dice "¿puedes hacer un estudio rápido de usuarios para validar nuestras suposiciones?", eso es rendimiento centrado en el usuario (user-centered performance). Ya es muy tarde para que importe. Tenemos que lanzar el producto. Lo que quieren es tachar la casilla.
context: At the opening of the podcast, Judd defines his concept of 'user-centered performance' - a phenomenon where teams go through the motions of being customer-obsessed without actually wanting to learn or change their decisions. He explains this is extremely common in product development, giving the example of PMs asking for validation studies at the end of product development when it's too late to actually incorporate findings.
vocabulary_highlights: hugely common, signal to each other, check the box
topics: Product Management, Decision Making, Communication Skills

speaker: Judd Antin
speaker_expertise: User Experience, Product Strategy, Team Building
text: One of my big mantras was, 'We don't validate, we falsify. We are looking to be wrong.' That is the mindset you should use when you're approaching insights and research. 'I want to be wrong. I want you to do research that shows we were off base in the following ways. Tell me exactly how and why in a way that allows me to fix it quickly.' But many PMs, many designers are not in that place. They do not want to be wrong. They're looking to validate. And that's user-centered performance.
text_ko: 제 큰 모토 중 하나는 "우리는 검증하는 게 아니라 반증해요. 우리는 틀리길 원해요."예요. 인사이트와 리서치에 접근할 때 그런 마음가짐을 가져야 해요. "내가 틀리길 바라요. 여러분이 우리가 다음과 같은 방식으로 빗나갔다는 걸 보여주는 리서치를 해주세요. 빠르게 고칠 수 있도록, 정확히 어떻게 그리고 왜 틀렸는지 알려주세요." 그런데 많은 제품 관리자들(PMs)과 디자이너들(designers)은 그런 태도가 아니에요. 틀리길 원하지 않아요. 검증하려고 하죠. 그리고 그게 바로 사용자 중심 성과(user-centered performance)에 머무르는 태도예요.
text_zh: 我一直坚持一个理念："我们不是为了验证，而是为了证伪。我们就是要找出自己哪里错了。" 这就是你做洞察和研究时应该有的心态。"我希望自己是错的。我希望你们做的研究能指出我们在哪些地方搞偏了。告诉我具体怎么偏了，为什么偏了，让我能快速调整过来。" 但很多产品经理(PM)、很多设计师都做不到这一点。他们不想承认自己错了，总想着去验证自己的想法。这其实是在做样子给用户看。
text_es: Una de mis frases favoritas era: "No validamos, falsificamos. Buscamos estar equivocados." Esa es la mentalidad que deberías tener cuando te acercas a los insights y la investigación. "Quiero estar equivocado. Quiero que hagas investigación que demuestre que estábamos totalmente fuera de lugar y de qué maneras. Dime exactamente cómo y por qué, de una forma que me permita arreglarlo rápido." Pero muchos PMs, muchos diseñadores no están en esa onda. No quieren estar equivocados. Buscan validar. Y eso es teatro centrado en el usuario.
context: Judd explains his philosophy about the proper mindset for conducting user research. He argues that effective research should aim to prove assumptions wrong rather than validate existing beliefs. This contrasts with user-centered performance, where teams conduct research seeking confirmation of decisions they've already made, rather than genuinely wanting to learn and potentially change course based on findings.
vocabulary_highlights: off base, not in that place
topics: Learning & Growth, Decision Making, Product Management

speaker: Judd Antin
speaker_expertise: User Experience, Product Strategy, Team Building
text: There's a vicious cycle that's been happening, is from where I sit, and this is what I hear from many, many researchers and research leaders, which is a lot of companies hired a lot of researchers with great intentions, didn't quite know how to integrate them. And UX research is a newer discipline, so maybe that's not surprising. We're still learning how to use it. 'Cool, let's evolve.' But a lot of companies hired these people, but they hired them into kind of like a service discipline, very reactive, not in the room, not integrated in the way I said.
text_ko: 제가 보기엔 계속 악순환이 일어나고 있어요. 많은 연구자들과 리서치 리더들에게서 들은 건데, 많은 회사가 좋은 의도로 연구자들을 많이 채용했지만 이들을 조직에 어떻게 녹여야 할지 잘 몰랐어요. UX 리서치(UX research)는 비교적 새로운 분야라서 그리 놀랍진 않아요. 아직 어떻게 활용할지 배우는 중이고, ‘좋네, 진화하자’ 하는 단계예요. 그런데 많은 회사가 이 사람들을 뽑긴 했지만 서비스를 제공하는 역할처럼, 말하자면 서비스형 역할(service discipline)로 채용해서 매우 반응형(reactive)이고 회의나 의사결정 자리에도 함께 있지 않고 제가 말한 방식대로 통합되지 않았어요.
text_zh: 从我的角度看，现在有个恶性循环在发生，我从很多很多研究员和研究团队负责人那里都听到这样的情况：很多公司当初是好心招了一堆研究员，但其实不太知道怎么把他们融入进来。UX研究(UX research)本来就是个比较新的领域，所以这样也不奇怪。我们都还在摸索怎么用好它。"行吧，那就慢慢发展呗。"但是很多公司虽然招了这些人，却把他们当成了服务性岗位，很被动，不让他们参与核心讨论，也没有像我刚才说的那样真正整合进去。
text_es: Hay un círculo vicioso que está pasando, desde mi perspectiva, y esto es lo que escucho de muchísimos investigadores y líderes de investigación: muchas empresas contrataron a montones de investigadores con muy buenas intenciones, pero no tenían ni idea de cómo integrarlos. Y la investigación UX es una disciplina bastante nueva, así que tal vez no sorprende tanto. Todavía estamos aprendiendo cómo usarla. "Bueno, vamos evolucionando." Pero muchas empresas contrataron a esta gente, pero los metieron como en una disciplina de servicio, súper reactiva, sin estar en las reuniones importantes, sin estar integrados de la manera que te digo.
context: Lenny asks why research should be more integrated when it seems like research has been less helpful than expected. Judd explains the vicious cycle where companies hired researchers during the ZIRP era with good intentions but positioned them as a service function rather than strategic partners. This reactive positioning prevents researchers from having input on the right questions to ask and building direct relationships with product teams.
vocabulary_highlights: vicious cycle, from where I sit, not in the room
topics: Leadership & Management, Strategy & Planning, Coaching & Development

speaker: Judd Antin
speaker_expertise: User Experience, Product Strategy, Team Building
text: The multimillion dollar button. And basically we did research which revealed that people weren't going down the purchase funnel because they were afraid. The calls to actions on the button was making them afraid that it would initiate a purchase when really it was just taking the next step. We changed the text on the button with help from our amazing content design, our UX writing team. We basically changed seven characters and made Airbnb millions of dollars, because what we found out was really simple. It was just like, 'Hey, this button feels scary. The CTA on the button feels scary.'
text_ko: 이건 수백만 달러를 만들어낸 버튼 얘기예요. 사실 조사해보니 사람들이 구매 퍼널(purchase funnel)을 끝까지 진행하지 않는 이유가 두려움 때문이었어요. 버튼에 적힌 콜 투 액션(CTA) 문구 때문에 누르면 바로 결제가 시작될까 봐 겁을 먹고 있었던 거죠. 실제로는 단지 다음 단계로 넘어가는 것뿐이었는데요. 그래서 우리의 훌륭한 콘텐츠 디자인(content design)과 UX 라이팅(UX writing) 팀의 도움으로 버튼 문구를 바꿨어요. 문자 7자만 바꿨는데 에어비앤비에 수백만 달러를 안겨줬어요. 우리가 알아낸 건 정말 단순했어요 — 사람들이 “이 버튼이 무서워요, 버튼의 콜 투 액션(CTA) 문구가 무섭게 느껴져요”라고 느끼고 있었던 거예요.
text_zh: 价值几百万美元的按钮。我们做了调研发现，用户在购买漏斗(purchase funnel)里走不下去，就是因为害怕。按钮上的行动召唤(call to action)让他们以为一点就会直接下单，其实只是进入下一步而已。后来我们和超棒的内容设计团队、用户体验写作(UX writing)团队一起，把按钮上的文字改了改。就改了七个字符，就给爱彼迎赚了几百万美元。因为我们发现的道理特别简单，就是"哎，这个按钮让人觉得可怕，按钮上的CTA让人害怕"。
text_es: El botón de varios millones de dólares. Básicamente hicimos una investigación que reveló que la gente no avanzaba en el embudo de compra (purchase funnel) porque tenía miedo. Las llamadas a la acción (calls to action) del botón les daba miedo porque pensaban que iba a procesar la compra cuando en realidad solo era para dar el siguiente paso. Cambiamos el texto del botón con ayuda de nuestro increíble equipo de diseño de contenido y redacción UX. Básicamente cambiamos siete caracteres y le hicimos ganar millones de dólares a Airbnb, porque lo que descubrimos era súper sencillo. Era como, 'Oye, este botón da miedo. El CTA del botón da miedo.'
context: Judd shares a famous example from Airbnb to illustrate how micro-level research can deliver massive business value quickly. When explaining that good research can be fast rather than slow, he describes how his team discovered through rapid user research that a button's call-to-action text was scaring users away from proceeding in the booking funnel, thinking it would immediately charge them when it was just the next step.
vocabulary_highlights: calls to actions, CTA, feels scary
topics: Product Management, Growth & Marketing, Decision Making

speaker: Judd Antin
speaker_expertise: User Experience, Product Strategy, Team Building
text: NPS is the best example of the marketing industry marketing itself. And the problem is this threatens many people's livelihoods, because there's an entire industry of consultants and software providers that want you to believe NPS is a useful and accurate metric. The problem is, the consensus in the survey science community is that NPS makes all the mistakes. So it's a garbage in, garbage out problem.
text_ko: NPS(넷 프로모터 스코어)는 마케팅 업계가 자기 업계를 홍보하는 가장 좋은 사례예요. 문제는 이게 많은 사람들의 생계를 위협한다는 거예요. 컨설턴트와 소프트웨어 제공업체들로 이루어진 거대한 산업이 NPS가 유용하고 정확한 지표라고 믿게 만들고 싶어하거든요. 그런데 설문조사 과학(survey science) 쪽의 합의는 NPS가 온갖 실수를 다 저지른다는 거예요. 결국엔 입력이 엉망이면 출력도 엉망인 문제(garbage in, garbage out)가 되는 셈이에요.
text_zh: NPS就是营销行业给自己做营销的最佳例子。问题在于这威胁到了很多人的饭碗，因为有一大堆咨询师和软件供应商都指着让你相信NPS是个有用又准确的指标吃饭。但问题是，调研科学界的共识是NPS犯了所有不该犯的错误。所以这就是典型的垃圾进垃圾出(garbage in, garbage out)的问题。
text_es: El NPS es el mejor ejemplo de cómo la industria del marketing se vende a sí misma. Y el problema es que esto amenaza el sustento de mucha gente, porque hay toda una industria de consultores y proveedores de software que quieren que creas que el NPS es una métrica útil y precisa. El problema es que el consenso en la comunidad de ciencias de encuestas es que el NPS comete todos los errores posibles. O sea, es un problema de "basura entra, basura sale" (garbage in, garbage out).
context: Lenny asks about Judd's strong opinions on NPS (Net Promoter Score). Judd argues that NPS is fundamentally flawed from a survey science perspective, despite being widely promoted by consultants and software companies. He explains that the survey science community recognizes NPS as methodologically unsound, making it an unreliable metric for measuring customer satisfaction and loyalty.
vocabulary_highlights: marketing itself, threatens many people's livelihoods, garbage in, garbage out
topics: Strategy & Planning, Growth & Marketing, Decision Making

speaker: Jules Walter
text: The reality with PMs is that within each of these buckets, there's so many skills and then you can feel overwhelmed, so my advice is really just start skill by skill. What I did specifically is I joined Slack, I was in ICPM. When you join a new company, especially if you're earlier in the mid-career, you really want to get good at things like execution, IQ skills, execution, product sense, strategy.
text_ko: PM(프로덕트 매니저)로서의 현실은 각 분야마다 정말 많은 스킬이 있어서 가끔은 압도당할 수 있어요. 그래서 제 조언은 정말 하나씩 스킬을 쌓아가는 거예요. 제가 구체적으로 했던 것은 Slack에 가입하고 ICPM에 참여한 거예요. 새로운 회사에 들어가면, 특히 경력이 중반쯤인 경우에는 실행(execution), IQ 스킬, 프로덕트 감각(product sense), 전략(strategy) 같은 것들을 잘 익히는 게 정말 중요해요.
text_zh: 做PM(产品经理)的现实情况是，每个领域里都有太多技能要掌握，很容易让人觉得压力山大。我的建议就是一个技能一个技能地来，别想着一口吃成胖子。我当时的做法是加入了Slack，还有ICPM这些社区。当你进入一家新公司，特别是如果你还处在职业发展的中期阶段，你真的需要在执行力、智商技能(IQ skills)、执行、产品感觉(product sense)、战略这些方面变得更强。
text_es: La realidad con los PMs es que dentro de cada una de estas categorías, hay tantas habilidades que te puedes sentir abrumado, entonces mi consejo es realmente empezar habilidad por habilidad. Lo que hice específicamente fue unirme a Slack, estaba en ICPM. Cuando te unes a una empresa nueva, especialmente si estás en la etapa intermedia de tu carrera, realmente quieres volverte bueno en cosas como ejecución, habilidades de IQ, ejecución, intuición de producto (product sense), estrategia.
context: Lenny asks Jules about the most important skills to develop as a PM to advance in one's career. Jules divides PM skills into two categories: IQ skills (hard skills like execution, product sense, strategy) and EQ skills (soft skills like communication, leadership). He emphasizes that rather than trying to improve everything at once, PMs should focus on developing one skill at a time, starting with the foundational IQ skills early in their career.
vocabulary_highlights: feel overwhelmed, skill by skill, mid-career

speaker: Jules Walter
text: When people tell me, 'Hey, I'm going to a interview at this company.' First question I ask is, 'How many mock interviews have you done?' And the answer typically is zero. It's, 'Oh, I read a bunch of stuff. I practiced in my head.' But I'm like, 'How many actual mock interviews have you done?' And I would recommend people to do dozens of those mock interviews.
text_ko: 사람들이 “나 이 회사 면접 보러 가요”라고 하면 제가 제일 먼저 묻는 게 “모의 면접(mock interviews)을 몇 번이나 해봤어요?”예요. 보통 대답은 한 번도 안 했다고 해요. “아, 자료는 많이 읽었고 머릿속으로 연습했어요”라고들 하는데, 저는 “진짜로 모의 면접(mock interviews)을 몇 번이나 해봤어요?”라고 다시 물어봐요. 저는 사람들에게 그런 모의 면접을 수십 번은 해보라고 권해요.
text_zh: 有人跟我说，"嘿，我要去某某公司面试了。"我第一个问题就是，"你做过几次模拟面试(mock interview)？"答案基本上都是零。他们会说，"哦，我看了好多资料，在脑子里练了练。"但我就问，"你到底做过几次真正的模拟面试？"我建议大家至少要做几十次模拟面试才行。
text_es: Cuando la gente me dice, 'Oye, tengo una entrevista en esta empresa.' La primera pregunta que les hago es, '¿Cuántas entrevistas simuladas has hecho?' Y la respuesta típicamente es cero. Es como, 'Ah, me leí un montón de cosas. Practiqué mentalmente.' Pero yo les digo, '¿Cuántas entrevistas simuladas de verdad has hecho?' Y yo les recomendaría a la gente hacer docenas de esas entrevistas simuladas.
context: Lenny asks Jules about building interview skills, which Jules identifies as a crucial but overlooked PM skill. Jules explains that getting into great companies like Slack is essential for career growth, but most people prepare poorly for interviews. He emphasizes that reading about interviews isn't enough - candidates need to practice actual mock interviews repeatedly to build this critical skill that opens doors to better opportunities.
vocabulary_highlights: mock interviews, practiced in my head, dozens of those

speaker: Jules Walter
text: What I do specifically is when I'm trying to learn something new, I try to think about what is an outcome that I could drive. And if I drive this outcome, it will be proof that I'm better at this thing. If we go back to this story of when I joined Slack, I didn't know anything, literally anything about growth. And I was telling myself, 'I hope they don't fire me.' But then the outcome I wanted is, within six months, I wanted to ship enough experiments that were successful, that drove activation by, let's say, X percent.
text_ko: 제가 구체적으로 하는 건, 새로운 걸 배우려고 할 때 어떤 성과를 만들어낼 수 있을지 먼저 생각하는 거예요. 그 성과를 만들어내면 그게 제가 그걸 더 잘하게 됐다는 증거가 되니까요. 슬랙에 합류했을 때 얘기로 돌아가면, 저는 진짜로 '그로스(growth)'에 대해 하나도 몰랐어요. 그래서 혼자 '제발 날 해고하지 않길'이라고 생각하고 있었죠. 그런데 제가 바랐던 결과는 6개월 안에 성공적인 실험(experiments)을 충분히 많이 진행해서 활성화(activation)를, 예를 들어 X%만큼 올리는 거였어요.
text_zh: 我的具体做法是，当我想学新东西的时候，我会想"我能达成什么结果？如果我真的做到了，那就证明我在这方面确实有进步了。"回到我刚加入Slack那会儿，我对增长(growth)真的是一窍不通，什么都不懂。当时心里想的就是"千万别被炒鱿鱼啊。"但是我给自己定了个目标：六个月内，我要做足够多的成功实验，把激活率(activation)提升个X个百分点。
text_es: Lo que hago específicamente es que cuando trato de aprender algo nuevo, me pongo a pensar: ¿qué resultado puedo lograr? Y si logro este resultado, va a ser la prueba de que ya domino mejor esta cosa. Si volvemos a la historia de cuando entré a Slack, no sabía nada, literalmente nada sobre growth. Y me decía a mí mismo: "Ojalá no me despidan." Pero entonces el resultado que quería era que en seis meses, quería lanzar suficientes experimentos exitosos que aumentaran la activación en, digamos, X por ciento.
context: Lenny asks Jules about his most effective methods for building PM skills. Jules explains his approach of creating forcing functions - setting concrete, measurable outcomes as proof of skill development. He uses his experience joining Slack as their first growth PM as an example, where despite knowing nothing about growth, he committed to driving specific activation improvements within six months, which forced him to rapidly learn the necessary skills.
vocabulary_highlights: drive an outcome, proof that I'm better, ship enough experiments, drove activation

speaker: Jules Walter
text: What I do then is I start asking questions like, 'Okay, I'm trying to drive activation for Slack. What are some frameworks that I should use to drive activation? What are best practices? What are examples?' I have a sense of the kind of question that, if I were to answer them, I'd be able to drive the outcome. And then what I do is I read a little bit, not a lot about the topic, just to make sure I'm asking the right question. Then I refine my questions and then I find the best people in the field and I just go talk to them.
text_ko: 그럼 저는 이렇게 질문을 던지기 시작해요. “음, 지금 슬랙(Slack)의 활성화(activation)를 이끌어내려고 하는데, 활성화를 이끌어내기 위해 어떤 프레임워크(frameworks)를 써야 할까? 베스트 프랙티스(best practices)는 뭐고, 사례(examples)는 어떤 게 있을까?” 이런 질문들에 답할 수 있다면 원하는 결과를 만들 수 있겠다는 감이 들어요. 그다음 관련 주제에 대해 조금 읽어보긴 하는데, 많이 읽지는 않고요—질문이 제대로 됐는지 확인할 정도만요. 그런 다음 질문을 다듬고, 해당 분야에서 제일 잘 아는 사람들을 찾아가서 그냥 만나서 이야기해요.
text_zh: 然后我就开始问一些问题，比如"好，我想提高Slack的用户激活率(activation)，我应该用什么框架来提升激活率？有什么最佳实践？有哪些案例可以参考？"我心里大概知道哪些问题如果能回答清楚的话，就能达到我想要的结果。接下来我会稍微读点相关资料，不用太多，主要是确保我问的问题是对的。然后我会完善一下我的问题，找到这个领域最牛的那些人，直接去跟他们聊。
text_es: Lo que hago entonces es empezar a hacer preguntas como: "Bueno, estoy tratando de impulsar la activación para Slack. ¿Qué metodologías debería usar para impulsar la activación? ¿Cuáles son las mejores prácticas? ¿Qué ejemplos hay?" Tengo una idea del tipo de pregunta que, si las pudiera responder, lograría el resultado que busco. Entonces lo que hago es leer un poquito sobre el tema, no mucho, solo para asegurarme de que estoy haciendo las preguntas correctas. Después refino mis preguntas y luego encuentro a los mejores expertos en el área y simplemente voy y hablo con ellos.
context: Jules continues explaining his systematic approach to learning new PM skills. After setting a concrete outcome goal, he works backwards by identifying the key questions he needs to answer. Rather than extensive reading, he does minimal research to formulate better questions, then seeks out experts in the field to learn directly from them. This approach helped him rapidly master growth principles at Slack by connecting with top practitioners like Bangaly Kaba from Facebook.
vocabulary_highlights: frameworks, best practices, refine my questions, find the best people in the field

speaker: Jules Walter
text: What I've seen is the path that we just talked about, join a startup and then from there go into different companies. And then the other path that is typical is being at a company and then switching product management, especially if you develop domain expertise and there's a need for a PM. So, that's even more frequent. Of course there's also acquisitions that sort of thing, but making that initial transition is really hard.
text_ko: 제가 본 바로는, 우리가 방금 이야기한 경로가 있어요. 스타트업에 들어가서 거기서 다른 회사로 가는 거죠. 그리고 또 하나의 일반적인 경로는 한 회사에서 일하다가 제품 관리(Product Management)로 전환하는 건데, 특히 특정 분야에 대한 전문성이 생기고 PM이 필요할 때 자주 일어나요. 물론 인수합병 같은 경우도 있지만, 그 초기 전환이 정말 어렵죠.
text_zh: 我看到的情况是，刚才咱们说的那条路，就是先加入初创公司，然后再跳到其他公司。另外还有一条比较常见的路子，就是在一个公司待着，然后转做产品经理，特别是如果你在某个领域有专业经验，公司又需要PM的话。这种情况其实更多见。当然了，也有通过收购这种方式的，但最开始那个转型真的挺难的。
text_es: Lo que he visto es el camino del que acabamos de hablar, meterte en una startup y de ahí saltar a diferentes empresas. Y luego está el otro camino que es típico: estar en una empresa y después cambiar a product management (gestión de producto), sobre todo si desarrollas expertise en el sector y hay necesidad de un PM. Eso es incluso más común. Por supuesto también están las adquisiciones y ese tipo de cosas, pero hacer esa transición inicial es realmente difícil.
context: Lenny asks Jules about his path into product management, specifically noting that Jules joined a startup as one of their first PMs. Jules explains that breaking into product management is extremely difficult and there isn't a set path. He identifies two main routes: joining a startup where you can take on PM responsibilities, or transitioning internally at an existing company where you've developed relevant domain expertise.
vocabulary_highlights: initial transition, domain expertise, acquisitions

speaker: Jules Walter
text: But externally, I'm like, 'Hey, thank you,' and I mean it. I think that's the key that most people don't focus on. And if you get more feedback, then you'll just get better at the things.
text_ko: 그래도 겉으로는 "고마워요"라고 말하고, 진심이에요. 그게 대부분 사람들이 잘 신경 쓰지 않는 핵심이라고 생각해요. 피드백을 더 받으면 그만큼 더 잘하게 돼요.
text_zh: 但是在外表上，我会说"嘿，谢谢你"，而且我是真心的。我觉得这就是关键点，大多数人都没有注意到这一点。如果你能得到更多反馈，你在这些事情上就会做得更好。
text_es: Pero por fuera, yo digo "Oye, muchas gracias" y lo digo en serio. Creo que esa es la clave en la que la mayoría de la gente no se enfoca. Y si recibes más retroalimentación (feedback), pues simplemente vas a mejorar en las cosas.
context: At the beginning of the episode, Jules is explaining his approach to receiving feedback. He describes how even when feedback is difficult to hear internally (his 'heart might be melting'), he always responds with genuine gratitude externally. This creates a reputation for being receptive to feedback, which encourages people to continue providing honest input that helps him improve his skills over time.
vocabulary_highlights: externally, focus on

speaker: Julia Schottenstein
speaker_expertise: Growth Strategy, Product Strategy, Data Analytics
text: When it comes to acquisitions, the time to start thinking about an M&A strategy is hopefully when you don't need one. And the best strategy that I could give a founder is to have a really strong offense in building their company. And when founders start their businesses, they don't usually set out to start a company to sell it to another business. They start it to be an enduring independent standalone company. And if you have that path, then you'll have the upper hand in absolutely every single M&A conversation because you have a viable alternative, which is do nothing, stay the course, you don't have to sell.
text_ko: 인수(acquisitions)에 관해서라면, M&A 전략(M&A strategy)을 생각하기 시작해야 할 시점은 운 좋게도 사실 그 전략이 필요하지 않을 때예요. 창업자에게 제가 드릴 수 있는 최고의 전략은 회사를 키우는 데 있어 정말 강한 공격 전략(offense)을 갖추는 거예요. 창업자들이 보통 회사를 시작할 때 다른 회사에 팔기 위해 시작하지는 않아요. 대개는 독립적이고 오래 지속되는 단독 기업(standalone)을 만들기 위해 시작하죠. 그런 길을 가지고 있다면 모든 M&A 대화에서 훨씬 우위를 점해요. 현실적인 대안, 즉 가만히 있어도 되고 현재 노선을 유지하면 되고 굳이 팔 필요가 없다는 선택지가 있기 때문이에요.
text_zh: 说到收购这事儿，最好是在你还不需要的时候就开始考虑并购(M&A)策略。我给创始人的最佳建议就是，把重点放在把自己公司做强上。创始人刚开始创业的时候，一般也不是为了卖给别人才开公司的，而是想做一家能长久发展的独立公司。如果你走的是这条路，那在任何并购谈判中你都能占上风，因为你有个很靠谱的选择——什么都不做，继续按原来的路走，不一定非得卖。
text_es: Cuando se trata de adquisiciones, lo ideal es empezar a pensar en una estrategia de M&A cuando no la necesitas. Y el mejor consejo que le puedo dar a un fundador es que se enfoque en construir su empresa con mucha fuerza. Porque cuando los fundadores arrancan sus negocios, normalmente no lo hacen pensando en vendérsela a otra empresa. Lo hacen para crear una compañía independiente que perdure. Y si tienes ese rumbo, entonces vas a tener todas las de ganar en cualquier conversación de M&A, porque tienes una alternativa real: no hacer nada, seguir tu camino, no tienes por qué vender.
context: Lenny asks Julia for advice for founders currently thinking about M&A acquisitions and how to be most successful. Julia explains that the best time to think about M&A strategy is when you don't desperately need it - having a strong independent business path gives you negotiating power. She emphasizes that founders should focus first on building a strong company that could succeed independently, as this creates optionality and leverage in any acquisition discussions.
vocabulary_highlights: have the upper hand, viable alternative, stay the course
topics: Starting a Company, Strategy & Planning, Decision Making

speaker: Julia Schottenstein
speaker_expertise: Growth Strategy, Product Strategy, Data Analytics
text: M&A is always about creating plan Bs. And the way I would think about it is for any one company, there's only ever two to three buyers that find what you're building to be extremely strategic. And the strategy that I would do in how do you get noticed is I would figure out the area that you bring a competitive advantage. And I would inflict pain on that potential buyer. Make it impossible for them to not notice you because that's when they're going to have their ears perk up and say, 'Well, what's going on with this company?'
text_ko: 인수합병(M&A)은 언제나 플랜 B(plan B)를 만드는 문제예요. 제 생각에는, 한 회사가 만드는 걸 진짜 전략적으로 보는 인수자(buyer)는 많아야 두세 곳뿐이에요. 눈에 띄게 하려면 제가 할 전략은 회사가 경쟁 우위(competitive advantage)를 가진 영역을 찾아내는 거예요. 그리고 그 잠재 인수자에게 압박을 가해서 못 본 척할 수 없게 만들 거예요. 그래야 그들이 귀를 쫑긋 세우고 "이 회사에 무슨 일이 있지?"라고 하게 되거든요.
text_zh: 并购其实就是给自己留后路嘛。我是这么看的，对于任何一家公司来说，真正觉得你在做的事情对他们有战略价值的买家，也就那么两三个。那怎么让他们注意到你呢？我的策略是，你得先搞清楚自己的竞争优势在哪儿，然后就在这个领域给潜在买家制造点压力。让他们没办法忽视你的存在，这样他们才会竖起耳朵想："咦，这家公司到底在搞什么名堂？"
text_es: Las fusiones y adquisiciones siempre se tratan de crear planes B. Y yo lo veo así: para cualquier empresa, solo hay dos o tres compradores que realmente van a ver lo que estás construyendo como algo súper estratégico. Y la estrategia que yo usaría para que te noten es identificar el área donde tienes ventaja competitiva. Y ahí les vas a meter presión a ese posible comprador. Hacerles imposible que no te noten, porque ahí es cuando se van a despertar y van a decir: "¿Qué está pasando con esta empresa?"
context: Julia is explaining her M&A strategy for founders looking to get acquired. She describes how to get noticed by potential acquirers - by identifying your competitive advantage and strategically competing with them in a way that forces them to pay attention. The concept of 'inflicting pain' means competing effectively enough that the potential buyer can't ignore your impact on their business, which makes them more likely to consider acquiring you.
vocabulary_highlights: inflict pain, have their ears perk up
topics: Starting a Company, Strategy & Planning, Competition

speaker: Julia Schottenstein
speaker_expertise: Growth Strategy, Product Strategy, Data Analytics
text: The really important piece here is you want to do that in a way that's still friendly and open. I see a lot of founders get this wrong and they prematurely will shut down a conversation or they won't talk to an incumbent or a potential future buyer because they take too competitive of a stance. But that's a mistake because M&A is all about creating plan Bs and you don't want to shut that door down prematurely because you don't know if you can really go the distance and be an independent company.
text_ko: 여기서 정말 중요한 건 그걸 여전히 우호적이고 개방적인 방식으로 해야 한다는 거예요. 많은 창업자들이 이걸 잘못해서 너무 경쟁적으로 나오다가 대화를 너무 일찍 닫거나 기존 업체나 잠재적 인수자와 아예 얘기조차 안 하는 경우를 많이 봐요. 그런데 그건 실수예요. 인수합병(M&A)은 플랜 B(plan B)를 만들어 두는 일이니까요. 독립 회사로 끝까지 갈 수 있을지 모르는 상황에서 그 가능성을 일찍 차버리면 안 돼요.
text_zh: 这里最关键的一点是，你要用一种友好开放的方式来处理这些事情。我看到很多创始人在这方面搞错了，他们会过早地中断对话，或者不愿意跟现有的公司或者潜在的收购方聊，因为他们把姿态摆得太有竞争性了。但这其实是个错误，因为并购(M&A)说到底就是给自己留后路，你不能过早地把这扇门关死，因为你也不知道自己到底能不能坚持到底，真的做成一家独立的公司。
text_es: Lo que realmente importa aquí es que hagas esto manteniendo un tono amigable y abierto. Veo que muchos fundadores la riegan en esto y terminan cortando conversaciones de manera prematura o no quieren hablar con empresas establecidas o posibles compradores porque se ponen muy competitivos. Pero eso es un error porque las fusiones y adquisiciones se tratan de crear planes B, y no quieres cerrar esa puerta antes de tiempo porque no sabes si realmente vas a poder llegar hasta el final como empresa independiente.
context: Julia continues explaining her M&A strategy, emphasizing the balance between competition and collaboration. After discussing how to 'inflict pain' on potential buyers, she warns that founders often make the mistake of being too aggressive or competitive, which closes off acquisition opportunities. She stresses that M&A is about creating backup plans (plan Bs) and maintaining optionality, since most companies can't successfully remain independent forever.
vocabulary_highlights: take too competitive of a stance, go the distance, shut that door down prematurely
topics: Starting a Company, Strategy & Planning, Networking

speaker: Julia Schottenstein
speaker_expertise: Growth Strategy, Product Strategy, Data Analytics
text: And when dbt was first getting started, you would hear a lot from companies, I don't understand, what's so special about dbt? We have a SQL templating tool at our company, we built one in-house. Like this is really straightforward and simple and it's true like dbt is really simple, but that is the power of it. So our founders, Tristan, Drew and Connor, they had a belief that the people who do data analysis work, that really work closely with their business stakeholders should also be the ones to contribute to creating clean data assets in production because that data prep work is a necessary prerequisite for any analysis that you do.
text_ko: dbt가 막 시작할 때 많은 회사에서 “dbt가 뭐가 그렇게 특별해요? 우리도 SQL 템플릿 도구(SQL templating tool)가 있고, 사내에서 직접 만들었어요”라는 반응이 많았어요. 사실 dbt가 정말 단순하다는 건 맞아요. 그런데 바로 그 단순함이 강점이에요. 그래서 창업자 Tristan, Drew, Connor는 데이터 분석(data analysis) 업무를 실제로 비즈니스 이해관계자들과 밀접하게 하는 사람들이 운영 환경(production)에서 깨끗한 데이터 자산(data assets)을 만드는 데 기여해야 한다고 믿었어요. 데이터 준비(data prep) 작업은 어떤 분석을 하든 반드시 선행돼야 하는 일이니까요.
text_zh: 当初dbt刚起步的时候，经常会听到一些公司说，我搞不懂，dbt有什么特别的？我们公司有自己的SQL模板工具，是我们内部开发的。这东西看起来很直接很简单嘛。确实，dbt就是很简单，但这恰恰就是它的厉害之处。所以我们的创始人Tristan、Drew和Connor，他们有个理念，就是那些做数据分析的人，那些真正和业务方紧密合作的人，他们也应该参与到生产环境中干净数据资产的创建工作中来，因为数据预处理(data prep)是你做任何分析之前都必须要做的事情。
text_es: Y cuando dbt apenas estaba empezando, escuchabas mucho de las empresas: "No entiendo, ¿qué tiene de especial dbt? Nosotros tenemos una herramienta de plantillas SQL (SQL templating tool) en nuestra empresa, la desarrollamos internamente. Esto es súper sencillo y directo." Y es cierto, dbt es realmente simple, pero ahí está su poder. Entonces nuestros fundadores, Tristan, Drew y Connor, tenían la convicción de que las personas que hacen análisis de datos, que realmente trabajan de cerca con los stakeholders del negocio, también deberían ser las que contribuyan a crear activos de datos limpios en producción, porque ese trabajo de preparación de datos es un prerequisito necesario para cualquier análisis que hagas.
context: Lenny asks Julia what dbt did right to become the default standard in the modern data stack. Julia explains one key factor was their focus on power through simplicity. She describes how other companies initially dismissed dbt as too simple since they had built similar tools in-house. However, dbt's founders believed that data analysts who work with business stakeholders should be empowered to create clean production data, not just data engineers, and dbt's simplicity made this possible.
vocabulary_highlights: in-house, necessary prerequisite

speaker: Julia Schottenstein
speaker_expertise: Growth Strategy, Product Strategy, Data Analytics
text: So dbt is really easy to get started with at your company with reduced friction. We're building a product that people, so they talk about it, they want to share it both at their organization and with other companies. Other companies get started with dbt again with reduced friction. We now get to see this really diverse set of use cases for dbt across company sizes, across industries and it allows us to build a truly horizontal company. As our company grows, we get to invest back into our community and our product and the flywheel begins to spin faster.
text_ko: 그래서 dbt는 회사에서 시작하기가 정말 쉬워요 — 진입 장벽이 낮아져서요(reduced friction). 저희는 사람들이 자연스럽게 이야기하고 조직 안팎에서 공유하고 싶어하는 제품을 만들고 있어요. 다른 회사들도 마찬가지로 진입 장벽이 낮아져서 다시 dbt를 도입하게 되고요. 덕분에 회사 규모나 업종을 가리지 않고 정말 다양한 dbt 활용 사례를 보게 됐고, 그걸 바탕으로 진정한 수평형 회사(horizontal company)를 만들어갈 수 있어요. 회사가 커질수록 저희는 커뮤니티와 제품에 더 투자할 수 있고, 플라이휠(flywheel)이 더 빨리 굴러가기 시작해요.
text_zh: 所以dbt在公司里特别容易上手，没什么阻力。我们做的这个产品呢，大家用了都爱聊，愿意在自己公司内部分享，也愿意跟其他公司分享。其他公司看到了也很容易就开始用dbt，同样没什么门槛。现在我们能看到dbt的使用场景特别丰富，各种规模的公司都在用，各个行业都有，这让我们能做成一个真正的横向平台型公司。随着我们公司越做越大，我们就能把更多资源投回到社区和产品上，这个飞轮(flywheel)就转得越来越快了。
text_es: Entonces dbt es súper fácil de implementar en tu empresa sin tantas complicaciones. Estamos creando un producto que a la gente le encanta, hablan de él, lo quieren compartir tanto en su organización como con otras empresas. Otras empresas empiezan a usar dbt también sin tanto rollo. Ahora vemos una variedad increíble de casos de uso para dbt en empresas de todos los tamaños, de todas las industrias, y eso nos permite construir una empresa verdaderamente horizontal. Conforme nuestra empresa crece, podemos reinvertir en nuestra comunidad y nuestro producto, y el volante (flywheel) empieza a girar más rápido.
context: Julia explains how dbt's open source strategy created powerful network effects and a flywheel for growth. She describes how dbt's low friction, easy-to-start approach led users to evangelizing the product both within their companies and to other organizations. This organic sharing created a diverse user base across different company sizes and industries, allowing dbt to become a horizontal platform. The growing user base then enabled more investment in community and product, accelerating the growth flywheel.
vocabulary_highlights: reduced friction, truly horizontal company, flywheel begins to spin faster
topics: Product Management, Growth & Marketing, Strategy & Planning

speaker: Julia Schottenstein
speaker_expertise: Growth Strategy, Product Strategy, Data Analytics
text: So we recently codified our philosophy when it comes to competition. And I'll give Nick Handel the founder of Transform who led this exercise at dbt Labs. But we really have three pillars when it comes to competition. So the first is hold true to our vision. We're really excited about the path and the journey that we're going on at dbt Labs and we don't want the distraction. So occasionally you'll have competitors maybe throw shade or throw stones, but most of that is just noise.
text_ko: 그래서 최근에 경쟁에 대한 우리 철학을 문서화했어요. 이 작업을 이끈 dbt Labs의 Transform 창업자 닉 핸델(Nick Handel)에게 공을 돌리고 싶어요. 경쟁에 관해서는 사실 세 가지 기둥이 있어요. 첫째는 우리 비전에 충실하는 거예요. dbt Labs에서 우리가 가는 길과 여정에 대해 정말 기대하고 있고, 그런 부분에서 산만해지고 싶지 않아요. 가끔 경쟁자들이 비난을 하거나 흠집을 내려 할 수도 있지만, 대부분은 그냥 잡음이에요.
text_zh: 我们最近把竞争理念给整理成文了。这个工作是我们Transform的创始人Nick Handel在dbt Labs主导的。我们对竞争有三个核心原则。第一个就是坚持我们的愿景。我们对dbt Labs现在走的路和发展方向特别兴奋，不想被其他事情分散注意力。偶尔会有竞争对手说三道四或者使绊子，但大部分都是噪音而已。
text_es: Entonces hace poco definimos nuestra filosofía respecto a la competencia. Y le doy el crédito a Nick Handel, el fundador de Transform, que lideró este ejercicio en dbt Labs. Pero básicamente tenemos tres pilares cuando se trata de competencia. El primero es mantenernos fieles a nuestra visión. Estamos súper emocionados con el rumbo y el camino que estamos tomando en dbt Labs y no queremos distracciones. Entonces de vez en cuando vas a tener competidores que tal vez te tiren hate o te critiquen, pero la mayoría de eso es puro ruido.
context: Lenny asks Julia how to think about competition and how much energy to put into watching competitors. Julia explains dbt's three-pillar philosophy for handling competition. The first pillar is staying focused on their own vision despite competitive distractions. She mentions that competitors sometimes 'throw shade' (criticize publicly) but emphasizes treating this as noise rather than letting it derail their strategic focus.
vocabulary_highlights: codified our philosophy, throw shade, throw stones

speaker: Julia Schottenstein
speaker_expertise: Growth Strategy, Product Strategy, Data Analytics
text: It's really like an all hands on deck conversation. Pricing is so cross-cutting because it's a finance discussion as well. You're modeling out things in spreadsheets and figuring out how that might impact the business. But you can't just solve these problems in spreadsheets. You have to go talk to customers, test the waters, understand where people's appetites are and sussing that out is really hard.
text_ko: 정말 전사적으로 다 같이 나서서 논의해야 하는 얘기예요. 프라이싱(pricing)은 여러 부서를 가로지르는 문제라 재무적인 부분과도 연결되어 있어요. 스프레드시트(spreadsheet)로 모델을 만들어 그게 비즈니스에 어떤 영향을 줄지 계산해보지만, 스프레드시트만으로는 해결할 수 없어요. 결국 직접 고객을 만나 얘기해보고, 반응을 테스트해서 사람들이 어느 정도 수요가 있는지 파악해야 하는데, 그걸 알아내는 게 정말 어려워요.
text_zh: 这就像是全公司都要参与的讨论。定价这个事儿特别复杂，因为它涉及到财务层面。你得在表格里建模型，算算对业务会有什么影响。但光靠表格是解决不了问题的，你必须去跟客户聊，试试水，摸清楚大家的接受度在哪儿——这真的很难搞清楚。
text_es: Es realmente como cuando necesitas a todo el equipo trabajando en algo. Los precios tocan todas las áreas porque también es un tema financiero. Estás modelando cosas en hojas de cálculo y viendo cómo puede impactar el negocio. Pero no puedes resolver estos problemas solo con números en Excel. Tienes que hablar con los clientes, tantear el terreno (test the waters), entender qué tan dispuestos están a pagar y descifrar eso es súper complicado.
context: Lenny asks Julia about dbt's first-ever pricing change and what that process was like. Julia describes how pricing decisions require collaboration across multiple departments - it's not just a product decision but involves finance, customer research, and business modeling. She emphasizes that while spreadsheet analysis is important, you must also conduct customer interviews to understand willingness to pay, though getting honest feedback about pricing from customers is challenging.
vocabulary_highlights: all hands on deck, cross-cutting, test the waters, sussing that out

speaker: Julian Shapiro
text: Why does Telegram, WhatsApp, iMessage, all these chat apps, Discord, grow so quickly? Pretty obviously because if you and your little clique of friends are having your conversation in that app, then the person who's also in your real life friend group, but who hasn't yet installed the app has to install the app in order to have the conversation with you.
text_ko: 텔레그램, 왓츠앱, 아이메시지 같은 채팅 앱들, 디스코드는 왜 이렇게 빠르게 성장할까요? 아주 분명한 이유는, 만약 당신과 친한 소규모 친구 무리가 그 앱에서 대화를 하고 있다면, 현실의 같은 친구 그룹에 속해 있지만 아직 앱을 설치하지 않은 사람은 그 대화에 끼려면 결국 그 앱을 설치해야 하기 때문이에요.
text_zh: 为什么Telegram、WhatsApp、iMessage这些聊天软件，还有Discord，都能发展得这么快？道理很简单啊，如果你和你那帮朋友都在用这个软件聊天，那么你现实生活中的其他朋友，要是还没装这个软件的话，为了能跟你们聊天，他们也得装上这个软件。
text_es: ¿Por qué Telegram, WhatsApp, iMessage, todas estas apps de chat, Discord, crecen tan rápido? Pues está clarísimo: si tú y tu grupito de amigos están teniendo sus conversaciones en esa app, entonces la persona que también está en tu círculo de amigos de la vida real, pero que todavía no se ha bajado la app, tiene que instalársela sí o sí para poder conversar contigo.
context: Lenny asks Julian to explain his concept of product-led acquisition (PLA) - using the product itself to grow the product rather than relying on paid ads or SEO. Julian is explaining the second category of PLA, which involves inviting people to join conversations that can only be accessed within your app. He argues this creates nearly guaranteed user growth because people must install the app to participate in critical social or business conversations with their friends or colleagues.
vocabulary_highlights: little clique, pretty obviously, real life friend group, has to install the app

speaker: Julian Shapiro
text: Most creators are resisting their bad ideas. If you sat down, scribbled a few thoughts in a blank document and just walked away because you weren't struck with gold, then you never actually finished the creative process. There's no way you would've come up with gold.
text_ko: 대부분의 크리에이터들은 별로인 아이디어를 밀어내요. 빈 문서 앞에 앉아 대충 몇 가지를 휘갈겨 적어놓고, ‘번뜩이는 아이디어’가 안 떠올랐다는 이유로 바로 자리를 뜨면 사실 창작 과정(creative process)을 끝까지 해본 게 아니에요. 그렇게는 대박 아이디어가 나올 리가 없어요.
text_zh: 大部分创作者都在抗拒自己的烂点子。如果你坐下来，在空白文档里随便写了几个想法，然后因为没有灵光一现就直接走人了，那你根本就没有完成创作过程。这样你怎么可能想出好东西来呢？
text_es: La mayoría de los creativos se resisten a sus ideas malas. Si te sientas, apuntas algunas ideas en un documento en blanco y te largas porque no se te ocurrió nada genial, entonces nunca terminaste el proceso creativo de verdad. No hay manera de que hubieras llegado a algo bueno.
context: Lenny asks Julian about his 'Creativity Faucet' framework for generating creative ideas. Julian explains that he discovered this process by studying prolific creators like John Mayer, Ed Sheeran, and Neil Gaiman. The Creativity Faucet concept treats creativity like a backed-up pipe where bad ideas (wastewater) must be emptied out before good ideas (clear water) can flow. Julian argues that most people give up too early in the creative process instead of pushing through the bad ideas to reach the good ones.
vocabulary_highlights: resisting their bad ideas, scribbled a few thoughts, weren't struck with gold, finished the creative process

speaker: Julian Shapiro
text: You have people who follow you for the quality of your brain, and you have people who follow you for sort of you being a glorified curator. If they're following you for being a curator, they're sort of what I call labor followers. They're following you for the work that you're doing, where you're finding cool, funny memes.
text_ko: 어떤 사람들은 당신의 사고력이나 통찰력 때문에 팔로우하고, 또 어떤 사람들은 당신이 멋지게 큐레이션해 주는 걸 좋아해서 팔로우해요. 후자에 해당하는 사람들은 제가 '노동형 팔로워(labor followers)'라고 부르는 유형인데, 그들은 당신이 멋있고 웃긴 밈(memes)을 찾아 올려주는 그 '일' 때문에 팔로우하는 거예요.
text_zh: 跟着你的人分两种：一种是冲着你的脑子来的，觉得你有想法；另一种就是把你当成一个高级筛选员。如果他们跟你是因为你的筛选能力，我觉得这些算是"劳动粉丝"吧——他们就是冲着你干的活儿来的，比如你能找到那些很酷很搞笑的梗。
text_es: Tienes gente que te sigue por la calidad de tu cerebro, y tienes gente que te sigue porque eres como un curador glorificado. Si te siguen por ser curador, son lo que yo llamo seguidores laborales. Te siguen por el trabajo que haces, por encontrar memes chéveres y divertidos.
context: Lenny asks Julian why he rarely tweets anymore despite having a large following. Julian explains his philosophy about different types of social media followers. He distinguishes between 'mind followers' who follow you for original thoughts and insights, versus 'labor followers' who follow you for curated content like memes and threads. Julian argues that mind followers have higher loyalty and are more likely to take action when you ask them to do something, while labor followers see you as interchangeable with other content curators.
vocabulary_highlights: glorified curator, labor followers, finding cool, funny memes

speaker: Julian Shapiro
text: I consider everything I write to be evergreen. I avoid writing things that I feel like are a drop in the pan, just like talking about a trend or something, something very newsy. I avoid that altogether and I'm just interested in writing stuff that'll be relevant for a long time.
text_ko: 제가 쓰는 모든 글은 에버그린(evergreen)하다고 생각해요. 트렌드처럼 잠깐 반짝하고 끝나는, 뉴스성 얘기 같은 건 안 쓰는 편이에요. 그런 건 아예 피하고 오래도록 의미 있고 유용한 내용만 쓰고 싶어요.
text_zh: 我写的所有东西都追求常青树(evergreen)的效果。我不会写那种昙花一现的内容，比如追热点啊、蹭流量什么的，那种很时效性的东西我完全不碰。我就专注写那些能长期有价值的内容。
text_es: Considero que todo lo que escribo es contenido perenne (evergreen). Evito escribir cosas que siento que son flor de un día, como hablar de una tendencia o algo así, algo muy de actualidad inmediata. Eso lo evito por completo y me interesa más escribir cosas que vayan a ser relevantes por mucho tiempo.
context: Lenny and Julian discuss the difference between Julian's web-based handbooks versus newsletter formats. Julian explains that he treats his handbooks as 'living assets' that he continuously updates over time, spending as many hours rewriting old content as creating new content. He emphasizes his focus on creating evergreen content that remains valuable long-term rather than writing about temporary trends or news cycles.
vocabulary_highlights: drop in the pan, something very newsy, evergreen

speaker: Julian Shapiro
text: One form of state is... One I did not cover is when you're embedded infrastructure. If you're Twilio, Striper, AWS, it's really hard to move off or segment because it's so much work to redo your code and introduce all this risk to screwing up your code base.
text_ko: 상태(state)의 한 형태로, 제가 언급하지 않았던 것 하나는 임베디드 인프라(embedded infrastructure)에 깊이 묶여 있을 때예요. 트윌리오(Twilio), 스트라이퍼(Striper), AWS 같은 곳에 의존하게 되면 그걸 떼어내거나 분리(segment)하기가 정말 어려워요 — 코드를 전부 다시 손봐야 하고 코드베이스(codebase)를 망칠 위험이 너무 크거든요.
text_zh: 有一种状态是...我刚才没讲到的是当你成为基础设施的一部分时。如果你是Twilio、Stripe、AWS这样的公司，客户真的很难迁移或者做切分，因为重写代码工作量太大了，而且搞不好还会把代码库弄坏，风险太高。
text_es: Una forma de estado es... Una que no mencioné es cuando eres infraestructura integrada. Si eres Twilio, Stripe, AWS, es súper difícil migrar o segmentar porque es muchísimo trabajo rehacer tu código e introduces un montón de riesgo de joder tu base de código.
context: Lenny asks Julian about retention strategies, and Julian explains his concept of 'building state' - encouraging users to accumulate non-transferable value within your product that makes them reluctant to switch to competitors. Julian describes how infrastructure companies like Twilio, Stripe, and AWS create natural stickiness because switching requires significant technical work and risk. This embedded infrastructure approach automatically creates retention without needing to add artificial switching costs.
vocabulary_highlights: embedded infrastructure, move off or segment, redo your code, screwing up your code base

speaker: Julian Shapiro
text: Writing quality equals novelty times resonance. Novelty is like we discussed, here are all these things that are giving you dopamine hits where I'm opening your eyes about how the world really works and shocking you and elegantly synthesizing things, times resonance.
text_ko: 글의 질은 새로움(novelty) 곱하기 공감(resonance)이에요. 여기서 새로움은 우리가 얘기한 것처럼 세상이 실제로 어떻게 돌아가는지 눈을 뜨게 하고 충격을 주며 우아하게 여러 정보를 종합해 도파민 반응(dopamine hits)을 일으키는 그런 모든 요소들이에요. 그걸 공감과 곱해야 진짜로 효과를 발휘해요.
text_zh: 写作质量等于新颖性乘以共鸣度。新颖性就是我们刚才说的，就是那些能让你多巴胺飙升的东西——让你大开眼界，了解世界真正的运作方式，给你震撼，还能优雅地把各种概念串联起来，这就是新颖性，然后再乘以共鸣度。
text_es: La calidad de la escritura es igual a la novedad multiplicada por la resonancia.
