La novedad es como platicamos, todas estas cosas que te dan esos picos de dopamina donde te abro los ojos sobre cómo funciona realmente el mundo y te sorprendo y sintetizo las cosas de manera elegante, multiplicado por la resonancia.
context: Lenny asks Julian about his framework for creating novel writing that keeps people engaged. Julian presents his equation for determining writing quality, where novelty (new, significant ideas people wouldn't easily think of themselves) must be multiplied by resonance (the storytelling power to make ideas memorable through examples, analogies, and stories). He explains that even the most novel information becomes just bland trivia without resonance to help it stick in readers' minds.
vocabulary_highlights: dopamine hits, elegantly synthesizing, times resonance

speaker: Julie Zhuo
speaker_expertise: Product Design, User Experience, Leadership Development
text: You want to diagnose with data and treat with design. So data is not a tool that's going to tell you what you should build. I don't actually think a lot of the fast growing companies are using data well at this point. Traditionally things just didn't grow that fast. These companies are totally getting by on just good instincts and good vibes, but what always happens is eventually things stop growing.
text_ko: 진단은 데이터(data)로 하고 처방은 디자인(design)으로 해야 해요. 그래서 데이터(data)가 '뭘 만들어야 할지'를 대신 알려주는 도구는 아니에요. 솔직히 지금 많은 급성장하는 회사들이 데이터를 잘 활용하고 있다고 보지 않아요. 원래는 기업들이 그렇게 빨리 성장하진 않았거든요. 지금 그런 회사들은 거의 직감과 좋은 분위기만으로 굴러가고 있는데, 결국엔 성장세가 멈추게 돼요.
text_zh: 你要用数据来诊断问题，用设计来治疗问题。所以数据不是告诉你该做什么产品的工具。说实话，我觉得现在很多快速增长的公司其实都没把数据用好。以前的公司增长没这么快，现在这些公司完全就是凭感觉和直觉在做，但问题是增长总会停下来的。
text_es: Tienes que diagnosticar con datos y tratar con diseño. O sea, los datos no son una herramienta que te va a decir qué tienes que construir. La verdad es que no creo que muchas de las empresas de crecimiento rápido estén usando bien los datos en este momento. Tradicionalmente las cosas no crecían tan rápido. Estas empresas se las están arreglando solo con buen instinto y buena onda, pero lo que siempre pasa es que al final las cosas dejan de crecer.
context: Lenny asks Julie about her transition from being head of design at Facebook to now running a data analytics startup. Julie explains her philosophy on the relationship between data and design, arguing that many fast-growing AI companies today haven't had time to build proper data infrastructure because they've scaled so quickly. She believes data should inform what problems to solve, but design creativity is still needed to determine the solutions.
vocabulary_highlights: diagnose with data and treat with design, getting by on just good instincts and good vibes
topics: Product Management, Decision Making, Strategy & Planning

speaker: Julie Zhuo
speaker_expertise: Product Design, User Experience, Leadership Development
text: Management is still really critical. You have a north star, you have a vision, and you're just trying to figure out how to use the resources that you have to get that thing done. Used to be people, but now it's basically models and different models have different strengths. You have to assemble the Avengers so that you can use the right tools for the right purposes.
text_ko: 매니지먼트는 여전히 정말 중요해요. 노스 스타(north star)와 비전이 있고, 그걸 이루기 위해 가진 자원을 어떻게 활용할지 고민하는 거예요. 예전엔 그게 사람이었지만, 지금은 사실상 모델(models)이 중심이에요. 모델마다 강점이 다르니, 목적에 맞는 도구를 쓰려면 어벤져스(Avengers)처럼 적절히 조합해야 해요.
text_zh: 管理还是超级重要的。你得有个北极星，有个愿景，然后想办法用手头的资源把事儿给办成。以前靠的是人，现在基本上就是各种模型，每个模型都有自己的强项。你得像组建复仇者联盟一样，把合适的工具用在合适的地方。
text_es: La gestión sigue siendo súper importante. Tienes tu estrella del norte (north star), tienes una visión, y básicamente estás tratando de descifrar cómo usar los recursos que tienes para lograr eso. Antes eran personas, pero ahora son básicamente modelos y cada modelo tiene sus propias fortalezas. Tienes que armar a los Vengadores para poder usar las herramientas correctas para los propósitos correctos.
context: Lenny mentions how organizations are flattening and many middle managers are being let go, questioning whether we still need managers. Julie explains that while the nature of management is changing with AI, the core principles remain the same - having a vision and coordinating resources to achieve it. The key difference is that instead of managing only people, managers now need to orchestrate both people and AI models with different capabilities.
vocabulary_highlights: assemble the Avengers

speaker: Julie Zhuo
speaker_expertise: Product Design, User Experience, Leadership Development
text: It's always been manager's job to manage change. I just think the rate of change is accelerating. Today management is really about this idea of be sturdy while being flexible. So I think about this metaphor a lot of the willow tree. It can survive a lot of storms, disasters, et cetera, but it's also very flexible.
text_ko: 관리자는 늘 변화를 관리해왔어요. 다만 변화의 속도(rate of change)가 빨라지고 있다고 생각해요. 요즘의 경영(management)은 튼튼함을 유지하면서도 유연해야 하는 것 같아요. 그래서 저는 버드나무를 자주 떠올려요. 버드나무는 많은 폭풍과 재난을 견뎌낼 수 있지만 동시에 아주 유연해요.
text_zh: 管理变化一直都是管理者的活儿。我觉得现在就是变化的节奏越来越快了。今天的管理说白了就是要做到既稳又灵活。我经常想到柳树这个比喻，它能扛过很多风暴、灾难什么的，但同时又特别有韧性。
text_es: Siempre ha sido trabajo del gerente manejar el cambio. Solo que creo que el ritmo de cambio se está acelerando. Hoy en día, la gestión se trata realmente de esta idea de ser sólido pero flexible a la vez. Así que pienso mucho en esta metáfora del sauce. Puede sobrevivir muchas tormentas, desastres y todo eso, pero también es muy flexible.
context: Lenny asks Julie what she feels is the biggest change in the role and daily work of managers with the rise of AI. Julie explains that while managing change has always been part of a manager's job, the pace of change is now much faster, creating more uncertainty and fear among employees. She uses the metaphor of a willow tree to describe the balance managers need - being strong enough to weather storms while remaining flexible enough to adapt.
vocabulary_highlights: be sturdy while being flexible, rate of change is accelerating

speaker: Julie Zhuo
speaker_expertise: Product Design, User Experience, Leadership Development
text: We need to dissolve the boundaries of these traditional roles and call ourselves builders. I'd love for us to get to the world where that's the title. It used to be, okay, I don't have the skills to do 10 different jobs, but now with AI allows me to do many of those jobs myself.
text_ko: 이런 전통적인 역할의 경계를 허물고 우리 스스로를 빌더(builders)라고 불러야 해요. 그게 직함이 되는 세상이 오면 좋겠어요. 예전엔 '난 10가지 일을 다 할 능력이 없어'라고 생각했지만, 이제는 인공지능(AI) 덕분에 그중 많은 일을 제가 직접 해낼 수 있어요.
text_zh: 我们得打破这些传统岗位的界限，都叫自己建设者就行了。我特别希望能到那个时候，这就是我们的头衔。以前是这样的，好吧，我没那个能力同时干10个不同的活儿，但现在有了AI，我自己就能搞定很多工作了。
text_es: Necesitamos romper las barreras de estos roles tradicionales y llamarnos constructores. Me encantaría que llegáramos a un mundo donde ese sea nuestro título. Antes era como "bueno, no tengo las habilidades para hacer 10 trabajos diferentes", pero ahora con la IA puedo hacer muchos de esos trabajos yo mismo.
context: Lenny discusses the trend of organizational flattening where everyone is becoming an individual contributor again. Julie argues that AI is empowering individuals to take on multiple roles that previously required different specialists. Instead of having traditional job titles like engineer, designer, or product manager, she believes we should all consider ourselves 'builders' who can use AI tools to perform various functions previously requiring separate team members.
vocabulary_highlights: dissolve the boundaries

speaker: Julie Zhuo
speaker_expertise: Product Design, User Experience, Leadership Development
text: If you ask a company to do this, we'll know that this is challenging for humans. I think a lot of times when you talk about why is alignment so difficult at a big company, it often comes down to this question, which is different people may have different pictures of what success looks like.
text_ko: 이걸 회사에 시켜 보면 사람들이 얼마나 어려워하는지 알 수 있어요. 큰 회사에서 왜 조율(alignment)이 그렇게 어려운지 얘기할 때, 많은 경우 결국 이 질문으로 귀결돼요 — 사람마다 성공이 어떤 모습인지에 대한 그림이 다를 수 있다는 거죠.
text_zh: 如果你让一家公司做这件事，我们就知道这对人来说确实很有挑战性。我觉得很多时候你谈到为什么大公司很难做到上下一心(alignment)，往往归根结底就是这个问题——不同的人对成功的定义可能完全不一样。
text_es: Si le pides a una empresa que haga esto, vamos a darnos cuenta de que es todo un reto para las personas. Creo que muchas veces cuando hablamos de por qué es tan difícil lograr alineación en una empresa grande, todo se reduce a esta pregunta: diferentes personas pueden tener ideas muy distintas de cómo se ve el éxito.
context: Lenny asks Julie about which management skills are most valuable when working with AI agents and tools. Julie explains that defining clear goals and success criteria is crucial - the same skill needed for managing people. She points out that even in human organizations, alignment is difficult because people often have different interpretations of what success means, making this skill even more critical when working with AI systems that need precise instructions.

speaker: Julie Zhuo
speaker_expertise: Product Design, User Experience, Leadership Development
text: I think the real promise and magic of AI that we're seeing in the workplace is that it leads us to each individual is far more empowered. So it used to be, okay, I don't have the skills to do 10 different jobs, so I need to supplement by hiring people to do these jobs. But now with AI and my companion, it's like, wait a second, AI allows me to do many of those jobs myself.
text_ko: 제 생각에는 직장에서 우리가 보는 인공지능(AI)의 진짜 가치이자 마법은 각 개인이 훨씬 더 역량을 갖게 된다는 거예요. 예전에는 제가 10가지 다른 일을 할 기술이 없어서 그런 역할들을 메우려고 사람을 더 채용해야 했죠. 그런데 이제는 인공지능(AI)과 그 AI 동반자(companion) 덕분에, 잠깐만, AI가 그런 일들 중 많은 부분을 제가 직접 해낼 수 있게 해줘요.
text_zh: 我觉得AI在职场上真正的魅力和潜力就是，它让我们每个人都变得更有能力了。以前是这样的，我一个人搞不定十个不同的工作，所以得雇人来做这些事儿。但现在有了AI这个助手，就不一样了，突然发现很多工作我自己就能搞定了。
text_es: Creo que la verdadera promesa y magia de la IA que estamos viendo en el trabajo es que cada persona puede hacer mucho más por sí sola. Antes era como "bueno, no tengo las habilidades para hacer 10 trabajos diferentes, entonces necesito contratar gente para esos puestos." Pero ahora con la IA como mi compañera, es como "espera un momento, la IA me permite hacer muchos de esos trabajos yo mismo."
context: Lenny asks about the trend of organizational flattening and whether we even need managers in the future. Julie explains that AI is fundamentally changing how work gets done by empowering individuals to perform tasks that previously required specialists. While someone might not reach the top 1% skill level in every area, AI can help them achieve competency levels that were previously impossible, reducing the need for large specialized teams.
vocabulary_highlights: real promise and magic of AI

speaker: Julie Zhuo
speaker_expertise: Product Design, User Experience, Leadership Development
text: I really believe that it's never a bad thing, it's always a better thing to have more feedback. And so, often, I think you don't necessarily want to be like, 'Oh, we have the one review meeting and that's the one in which we get everyone's opinions out and we make all these decisions, and then we're done.' I think about product and feedback as just the more, the better.
text_ko: 저는 피드백은 많을수록 결코 나쁜 게 아니라 항상 더 좋은 거라고 정말 믿어요. 그래서 종종 '한 번의 리뷰 미팅(review meeting)에서만 다들 의견을 모아서 모든 결정을 내리고 끝내자'라고 할 필요는 없다고 생각해요. 저는 프로덕트(product)와 관련해서도 피드백은 그냥 많을수록 좋다고 봐요.
text_zh: 我觉得反馈这个事情，永远不嫌多，越多越好。所以我经常想，你不能说"哦，我们就开这一次评审会，大家把意见都说完，决策都做完，然后就结束了。"我对产品和反馈的看法就是，多多益善。
text_es: Yo creo firmemente que nunca está de más tener más retroalimentación (feedback), siempre es mejor. Y por eso, muchas veces pienso que no necesariamente querés decir 'Bueno, tenemos esa única reunión de revisión donde sacamos todas las opiniones, tomamos todas las decisiones, y ya está.' Yo veo el producto y la retroalimentación (feedback) como que mientras más, mejor.
context: Lenny asks Julie about how companies should structure product review meetings and design critiques. Julie explains her philosophy on gathering feedback during product development. She emphasizes that feedback collection should be an ongoing process rather than a single decisive meeting, and that getting diverse perspectives from different groups (designers, team members, external users, target customers) will all provide valuable but potentially contradictory insights.

speaker: Julie Zhuo
speaker_expertise: Product Design, User Experience, Leadership Development
text: The number one advice that I always have for people when talking about product sensor or product thinking is it's just really about observation and it's about curiosity and can start by first observing yourself. Every time you're going to go and use something, every time you're going to have a new experience, you download an app, you try something new, it's take the moment to reflect on your emotion or your assumption at every step.
text_ko: 제가 제품 센서(product sensor)나 제품 사고(product thinking)에 대해 얘기할 때 항상 제일 먼저 드리는 조언은, 사실 그냥 관찰하고 호기심을 가지라는 거예요. 그건 먼저 자기 자신을 관찰하는 것부터 시작할 수 있어요. 뭔가를 쓰거나 새로운 경험을 할 때—앱을 다운받거나 새로운 걸 시도할 때마다—매 단계에서 느끼는 감정이나 가지고 있는 가정을 잠깐씩 되돌아보세요.
text_zh: 我给大家谈产品感觉或者产品思维时，最重要的一个建议就是，其实就是要多观察，要有好奇心，而且可以先从观察自己开始。每次你要去用什么东西，每次你要体验新的东西，下载个app，尝试新玩意儿的时候，都花点时间想想你在每个步骤中的感受和想法是什么。
text_es: El consejo más importante que siempre doy cuando hablamos de intuición de producto o pensamiento de producto es que realmente se trata de observación y curiosidad, y puedes empezar observándote a ti mismo. Cada vez que vayas a usar algo, cada vez que tengas una experiencia nueva, te descargues una app o pruebes algo diferente, tómate un momento para reflexionar sobre tu emoción o lo que asumes en cada paso.
context: Lenny asks Julie for advice on how people can develop better product sense and product thinking skills. Julie explains that developing product intuition starts with careful self-observation - paying attention to your own user experience when trying new products or services. This involves reflecting on emotions, assumptions, and behaviors at each step of the user journey, from what motivated you to try something to where you got confused or excited during the experience.
vocabulary_highlights: product sensor, take the moment to reflect

speaker: Julie Zhuo
speaker_expertise: Product Design, User Experience, Leadership Development
text: Being in an uncomfortable situation, being in a position where you feel like, Hey, do I really know how to do this? I've not prepared for it is kind of coin sides with the fastest and most intense periods of growth in one's career. And I started to realize, well, maybe it's not so much of a bad thing.
text_ko: 불편한 상황에 놓여서 ‘이걸 정말 할 줄 아는 걸까? 준비가 안 됐는데…’라고 느낄 때가 경력에서 가장 빠르고 강렬하게 성장하는 시기와 종종 동전의 양면이에요. 그래서 이게 꼭 나쁜 것만은 아닐지도 모르겠다고 생각하기 시작했어요.
text_zh: 处在一个让你不舒服的环境里，感觉"哎呀，我真的会做这个吗？我根本没准备好啊"——其实这种状态往往和职场上最快速、最强烈的成长期是一体两面的。后来我慢慢意识到，这可能也不是什么坏事。
text_es: Estar en una situación incómoda, estar en una posición donde sientes como que "¿de verdad sé hacer esto? No me he preparado para esto" va de la mano con los períodos de crecimiento más rápidos e intensos en tu carrera. Y empecé a darme cuenta de que, bueno, tal vez no es algo tan malo después de todo.
context: Lenny asks Julie about her rapid career progression from designer to VP of Design at Facebook, and how others can achieve similar success. Julie explains that she experienced imposter syndrome for 7-8 years, constantly feeling unprepared for her roles. However, she came to realize that feeling uncomfortable and unprepared is actually the flip side of experiencing rapid professional growth - when you're constantly challenged by new situations, you're forced to learn and develop quickly.
vocabulary_highlights: coin sides with, not so much of a bad thing

speaker: Julie Zhuo
speaker_expertise: Product Design, User Experience, Leadership Development
text: The most important feedback I would say is focus on identifying the problem and making it really clear for the other person, the person you're giving feedback to, what is the problem. There's a lot of assumptions that are already in place. You are giving that because you assume the current thing is insufficient in some way, and it's maybe not ideal at being clear, or it is forgetting to bring some important value prop, or maybe yellow just makes this whole thing look pukey or whatever it is.
text_ko: 제가 생각하는 가장 중요한 피드백은 문제를 찾아내는 데 집중하고, 그 문제가 피드백을 받는 사람에게 뭔지 정말 분명하게 알려줘야 한다는 거예요. 이미 많은 가정(assumptions)이 깔려 있는 경우가 많고요. 보통은 지금 상태가 뭔가 부족하다고 가정해서 피드백을 주는 건데, 설명이 애매하다든가 중요한 가치 제안(value prop)을 빠뜨리고 있다든가, 아니면 단순히 노란색 때문에 전체적으로 보기 안 좋게 보일 수도 있고, 뭐 그런 식이에요.
text_zh: 我觉得最重要的反馈就是要把问题说清楚，让对方真正明白问题出在哪儿。其实很多时候我们心里已经有各种假设了，你之所以要给反馈，肯定是觉得现在这个东西有什么地方不够好，可能是表达不够清晰，或者忘了突出一些重要的卖点(value prop)，再或者就是黄色让整个东西看起来很恶心，反正就是各种问题。
text_es: Lo más importante al dar feedback, yo diría que es enfocarte en identificar bien el problema y dejárselo súper claro a la otra persona, a quien le estás dando el feedback, cuál es exactamente el problema. Hay un montón de suposiciones que ya están ahí desde el principio. Tú estás dando ese feedback porque asumes que lo que hay ahora no está funcionando del todo bien, y tal vez no está siendo lo suficientemente claro, o se está olvidando de resaltar alguna propuesta de valor (value prop) importante, o a lo mejor ese color amarillo hace que todo se vea horrible, o lo que sea.
context: Lenny asks Julie for advice on how colleagues (PMs, engineers, data scientists) should give feedback to designers during critiques. Julie emphasizes that people should focus on clearly articulating the underlying problem rather than jumping straight to solutions. She explains that when people say things like 'make the logo purple' or 'add this feature,' they're making assumptions about solutions without first establishing what specific problem needs to be solved.
vocabulary_highlights: value prop, look pukey

speaker: Julie Zhuo
speaker_expertise: Product Design, User Experience, Leadership Development
text: What actually started me on this writing journey was a piece of feedback I got during a performance review cycle, and I remember I was talking to my manager and he shared that, 'Hey, one of the pieces of something you should work on, an area of growth is that you have a lot of really great ideas, and you're always really engaged whenever discussions happen in a small forum, one on one, or there's like two or three people in the room, but whenever there's a large room, we're talking about seven people, 10 people, 15 people, you're just sort of quiet and you're not really telling your perspective.'
text_ko: 사실 제가 이 글쓰기 여정을 시작하게 된 계기는 성과 리뷰에서 받은 피드백이었어요. 그때 매니저와 이야기하면서 그가 이렇게 말했어요. "너는 정말 좋은 아이디어가 많고, 소규모 포럼이나 일대일 대화에서는 항상 적극적으로 참여하는데, 큰 방에서는, 예를 들어 7명, 10명, 15명 정도가 모이면 좀 조용해지고 네 의견을 잘 이야기하지 않는 것 같아."
text_zh: 其实我开始写作这条路，完全是因为一次绩效评估(performance review)时收到的反馈。我记得当时跟我老板聊天，他跟我说："嘿，有个地方你需要提升一下，就是你其实想法挺多的，也很不错，平时小范围讨论的时候，比如一对一聊天，或者就两三个人在场的时候，你总是很积极参与，但是一到人多的场合，七八个人、十来个人、十五个人这种大会议，你就不怎么说话了，也不太表达自己的观点。"
text_es: Lo que realmente me llevó a empezar este camino de escribir fue un comentario que me dieron en una evaluación de desempeño. Me acuerdo que estaba hablando con mi jefe y me dijo: "Oye, algo en lo que deberías trabajar, un área de mejora, es que tienes ideas muy buenas y siempre participas mucho cuando hay conversaciones en grupos pequeños, cuando estamos uno a uno o cuando somos dos o tres personas, pero cuando hay mucha gente en la sala, digamos siete, diez, quince personas, como que te quedas callado y no compartes realmente tu punto de vista."
context: Lenny asks Julie about what got her started with writing and what impact it has had on her career. Julie explains that her writing journey began as a response to performance feedback about her reluctance to speak up in large meetings. Her manager pointed out that while she was engaged in small group discussions, she became quiet in larger forums with 7-15 people, and suggested she work on contributing her perspective in those settings.
vocabulary_highlights: small forum, telling your perspective

speaker: Julie Zhuo
speaker_expertise: Product Design, User Experience, Leadership Development
text: My number one advice is try to find an angle that's going to work for you because if you find yourself writing for your audience, if you find yourself writing because you want likes or you want a certain number of views, that actually is a really hard barrier to overcome because you don't have control over all of that. But if you write because you're trying to work on a particular key skill, whether it is clarity of thinking, whether it's helping you work through some stuff that's complicated in your mind, whether it's just, again, working on being more comfortable, putting your voice out there, then make it a goal, but make it a action goal.
text_ko: 제일 먼저 드리고 싶은 조언은 본인에게 통할 만한 각도(approach)를 찾아보라는 거예요. 청중(audience)을 위해 쓰거나 좋아요나 특정 조회수 때문에 쓰게 되면 그런 건 통제가 잘 안 돼서 넘기기 정말 힘든 장벽이 되거든요. 대신 특정 핵심 역량(key skill)을 키우기 위해, 사고의 명확성(clarity of thinking)을 다듬기 위해, 머릿속 복잡한 걸 정리하기 위해, 혹은 그냥 목소리를 내는 데 더 익숙해지기 위해 쓴다면 목표를 세우되 그냥 목표가 아니라 실행 목표(action goal)로 세우세요.
text_zh: 我的头号建议就是，你得找到一个适合自己的切入点。因为如果你老想着为观众写，或者就想着要多少赞、多少浏览量，这其实特别难突破，因为这些东西你根本控制不了。但是如果你写作是为了锻炼某个核心技能，比如让思路更清晰，或者帮你理清一些复杂的想法，再或者就是让自己更敢于表达观点，那就把这个当目标，但一定要是个行动目标。
text_es: Mi consejo número uno es que encuentres un enfoque que te funcione, porque si te pones a escribir para tu audiencia, si escribes porque quieres likes o un cierto número de visualizaciones, eso en realidad es una barrera súper difícil de superar porque no tienes control sobre todo eso. Pero si escribes porque estás tratando de trabajar en una habilidad clave específica, ya sea para tener más claridad mental, ya sea para ayudarte a procesar cosas que están complicadas en tu cabeza, o simplemente para sentirte más cómodo poniendo tu voz ahí afuera, entonces hazlo tu meta, pero que sea una meta de acción.
context: Lenny asks Julie if she would recommend writing as a tool for others who want to work on specific skills like clarity of communication. Julie responds with advice for people who want to start writing but find it difficult. She emphasizes that writing should be driven by personal development goals rather than external validation like likes or views, since you can't control audience response but you can control your own actions and skill development.
vocabulary_highlights: find an angle, hard barrier to overcome, putting your voice out there, action goal

speaker: Karina Nguyen
speaker_expertise: AI/ML Products, User Experience, Data Analytics
text: Model training is more an art than a science. And in a lot of ways we, as model trainers, think a lot about data quality. It's one of the most important things in model training is like how do you ensure the highest quality data for certain interaction model behavior that you want to create?
text_ko: 모델 학습(model training)은 과학이라기보다 예술에 더 가깝다고 생각해요. 그리고 여러 면에서 저희 모델 트레이너(model trainers)들은 데이터 품질에 대해 많은 고민을 해요. 모델 학습에서 가장 중요한 것 중 하나는, 원하는 특정 상호작용 모델의 행동(interaction model behavior)을 만들어내기 위해 어떻게 하면 최고 품질의 데이터를 확보하느냐 하는 거예요.
text_zh: 模型训练说白了更像是门艺术，而不是纯科学。我们做模型训练的人，其实很大程度上都在琢磨数据质量这个事儿。在模型训练里头，最关键的就是怎么保证数据质量够高，这样才能训出你想要的那种交互行为。
text_es: El entrenamiento de modelos es más un arte que una ciencia. Y de muchas maneras nosotros, como entrenadores de modelos (model trainers), pensamos muchísimo en la calidad de los datos. Una de las cosas más importantes en el entrenamiento de modelos es cómo te aseguras de tener datos de la más alta calidad para crear el comportamiento específico que quieres en tu modelo de interacción.
context: Lenny asks Karina what people most misunderstand about how AI models are created. Karina explains that model training involves a careful balance of teaching models contradictory information - like telling them they don't have physical bodies while also teaching them to perform functions like setting alarms. She emphasizes that the process requires constant debugging and balancing between making models helpful versus preventing harmful behavior.
vocabulary_highlights: more an art than a science, model trainers, interaction model behavior

speaker: Karina Nguyen
speaker_expertise: AI/ML Products, User Experience, Data Analytics
text: When you taught the model, some of the self-knowledge of you actually don't have a physical body to operate in the physical world, the model would get extremely confused. And so the model would get extremely confused about whether it can set an alarm, but it doesn't have a body in the physical world.
text_ko: 모델(model)에게 '자기 자신은 실제 세계에서 작동할 물리적 몸이 없다'는 식의 자기 지식(self-knowledge)을 알려주면, 모델이 아주 혼란스러워해요. 그래서 물리적 몸이 없으니 알람을 설정할 수 있는지 같은 문제에서 특히 엄청 헷갈려해요.
text_zh: 你在训练模型的时候，如果告诉它一些关于自己的认知，比如说它其实没有实体身体，不能在现实世界里操作，模型就会特别懵圈。所以模型就会对自己能不能设闹钟这种事情特别纠结，因为它在现实世界里根本就没有身体嘛。
text_es: Cuando entrenaste el modelo, parte del autoconocimiento de que en realidad no tienes un cuerpo físico para operar en el mundo físico, el modelo se confundía muchísimo. Entonces el modelo se volvía súper confuso sobre si puede poner una alarma, pero no tiene un cuerpo en el mundo físico.
context: Lenny asks what people misunderstand about model creation. Karina shares a specific example from training Claude 3 where they discovered conflicts in the training data. The model was taught it has no physical body, but also learned function calls for tasks like setting alarms, creating confusion about what it could actually do. This illustrates the complex debugging process required in model training.
vocabulary_highlights: self-knowledge, get extremely confused

speaker: Karina Nguyen
speaker_expertise: AI/ML Products, User Experience, Data Analytics
text: I think there are two questions here. We can unpack one at a time. But people say we are hitting the data wall. I think people think more in the terms of pre-trained large models that are trained on the entire internet to predict the next token.
text_ko: 여기에는 두 가지 질문이 있는 것 같아요. 하나씩 차근차근 풀어볼게요. 그런데 사람들은 우리가 '데이터 장벽(data wall)'에 부딪히고 있다고 말해요. 제 생각엔 사람들이 인터넷 전체를 학습해 다음 토큰을 예측하도록 훈련된, 이른바 사전 학습된 대형 모델(pre-trained large models) 관점으로 더 생각하는 것 같아요.
text_zh: 我觉得这里有两个问题，我们可以一个一个来分析。但是大家都在说我们碰到了数据墙(data wall)。我觉得人们更多想到的是那种在整个互联网上训练的预训练大模型(pre-trained large models)，用来预测下一个token的那种。
text_es: Creo que aquí hay dos preguntas. Las podemos desglosar una por una. Pero la gente dice que estamos llegando al muro de datos (data wall). Creo que la gente piensa más en términos de modelos grandes preentrenados que se entrenan con todo el internet para predecir el siguiente token.
context: Lenny asks about the concern that AI models will stop getting smarter because they're running out of training data. Karina addresses the misconception about the 'data wall' - the idea that models can't improve further because they've already been trained on all available internet data. She argues this view is too narrow and focuses only on pre-training phases.
vocabulary_highlights: unpack one at a time, hitting the data wall, predict the next token

speaker: Karina Nguyen
speaker_expertise: AI/ML Products, User Experience, Data Analytics
text: But I think what's happening right now with new paradigm of o1 series is that the scaling in post-training itself is not hitting the wall. And that's because basically we went from raw data sets from pre-trained models to infinite amount of tasks that you can teach the model in the post-training world via reinforcement learning.
text_ko: 제 생각에는 지금 o1 시리즈(o1 series)의 새로운 패러다임에서 벌어지는 건, 사후 훈련(post-training) 자체의 스케일링(scaling)이 한계에 닿지 않고 있다는 거예요. 그 이유는 기본적으로 우리가 사전 학습된 모델(pre-trained models)에 쓰던 원시 데이터셋(raw data sets)에서, 사후 훈련 환경에서는 강화학습(reinforcement learning)을 통해 모델에 가르칠 수 있는 태스크(tasks)가 무한히 많아졌기 때문이에요.
text_zh: 但我觉得现在o1系列这个新范式(paradigm)出现后，后训练(post-training)阶段的扩展其实还没碰到瓶颈。主要原因就是，我们从预训练模型(pre-trained models)的原始数据集，转向了后训练阶段通过强化学习(reinforcement learning)能教给模型的无限多任务，这个变化挺大的。
text_es: Pero creo que lo que está pasando ahora con el nuevo paradigma de la serie o1 es que el escalamiento en el post-entrenamiento no está llegando al límite. Y eso es porque básicamente pasamos de conjuntos de datos en bruto de modelos pre-entrenados a una cantidad infinita de tareas que le puedes enseñar al modelo en el mundo del post-entrenamiento a través del aprendizaje por refuerzo (reinforcement learning).
context: Lenny asks about synthetic data and whether models will continue getting smarter despite data limitations. Karina explains why she believes the 'data wall' concern is misguided. The o1 series represents a new paradigm where models can be taught infinite tasks during post-training through reinforcement learning, rather than being limited by finite internet data during pre-training.
vocabulary_highlights: new paradigm, scaling in post-training, hitting the wall, infinite amount of tasks

speaker: Karina Nguyen
speaker_expertise: AI/ML Products, User Experience, Data Analytics
text: Creative thinking and you kind of want to generate a bunch of ideas and filter through them and not just build the best product experience. I think it's actually really, really hard to teach the model how to be aesthetic or really good visual design or how to be extremely creative in the way they write.
text_ko: 창의적 사고에서는 아이디어를 많이 내서 그중에서 걸러내는 과정이 필요해요. 단순히 최고의 제품 경험(product experience)만 만드는 게 아니죠. 솔직히 모델(model)한테 미적 감각(aesthetic)이나 뛰어난 비주얼 디자인(visual design), 글을 쓸 때 아주 창의적으로 표현하는 법을 가르치는 건 정말, 정말 어렵다고 생각해요.
text_zh: 创意思维就是你得想出一堆点子，然后从中筛选，而不是只盯着做最好的产品体验。我觉得要教模型怎么做出有美感的东西，或者真正好的视觉设计，或者写出特别有创意的文案，这些真的超级难。
text_es: El pensamiento creativo, ¿sabes?, como que quieres generar un montón de ideas y filtrarlas, no solo crear la mejor experiencia de producto. Creo que en realidad es súper, súper difícil enseñarle al modelo cómo ser estético o tener un diseño visual realmente bueno, o cómo ser extremadamente creativo en la forma de escribir.
context: Lenny asks what skills will be most valuable for product teams as AI advances. Karina emphasizes that creative thinking will become increasingly important - the ability to generate many ideas and filter through them effectively. She explains that current AI models struggle with aesthetic judgment, high-quality visual design, and truly creative writing, making these human skills more valuable.
vocabulary_highlights: generate a bunch of ideas, filter through them
topics: Career Development, Product Management, Learning & Growth

speaker: Karina Nguyen
speaker_expertise: AI/ML Products, User Experience, Data Analytics
text: For Canvas, for example, it came down to three main behaviors. It was how do you trigger Canvas for prompts like, 'Write me a long essay,' when the user intention is mostly iterating over long documents? Or, 'Write me a piece of code,' or when to not trigger Canvas for prompts like, 'Can you tell me more about President...' I don't know, some of the general questions.
text_ko: 예를 들어 캔버스(Canvas)의 경우, 핵심 행동이 크게 세 가지로 정리됐어요. '긴 에세이를 써줘' 같은 프롬프트(prompt)는 사용자가 주로 긴 문서를 반복해서 다듬으려는 의도일 때 캔버스(Canvas)를 언제 불러올지, '코드 한 조각 작성해줘' 같은 경우는 언제 불러올지, 반대로 '대통령에 대해 더 알려줄래?'처럼 일반적인 질문에는 언제 캔버스(Canvas)를 띄우지 말아야 할지에 관한 것이었어요.
text_zh: 拿Canvas来说吧，主要就是三个行为模式。比如什么时候该触发Canvas，像用户说"帮我写篇长文章"，但其实用户想要的是在长文档上反复修改；或者"帮我写段代码"；还有什么时候不该触发Canvas，比如用户问"你能跟我说说某某总统..."这种，就是一些常规问题。
text_es: Con Canvas, por ejemplo, se reducía a tres comportamientos principales. Era cómo activar Canvas para comandos como "Escríbeme un ensayo largo", cuando la intención del usuario es principalmente iterar sobre documentos extensos. O "Escríbeme un código", o cuándo no activar Canvas para comandos como "¿Me puedes contar más sobre el Presidente...?" No sé, algunas de las preguntas generales.
context: Lenny asks how Canvas was created using synthetic data training. Canvas is OpenAI's collaborative document editing interface that changes from a chat to a visual editor. Karina explains they identified three core behaviors to teach the model: when to trigger the Canvas interface, how to edit documents, and how to make comments. The first behavior involved teaching the model to distinguish between requests that need document iteration versus simple Q&A.
vocabulary_highlights: came down to, user intention, iterating over long documents

speaker: Karri Saarinen
text: My belief is that, like any domain or industry, the more it matters, the more the design matters. What happens is whenever there's a new paradigm, I don't know, like the mobile or the web or something the first iterations of those products existing there, they don't have to be super well designed necessarily because they are the first. Then, as you build the 100,000 different email clients, any email client now has to be pretty good to be even considered an email client. It's like the bar is so high.
text_ko: 제 생각에는 어떤 분야나 산업이든 영향력이 클수록 디자인이 더 중요해요. 새로운 패러다임(paradigm)이 등장하면, 예를 들어 모바일(mobile)이나 웹(web)처럼 처음 나오는 제품들은 꼭 디자인이 완벽할 필요가 없어요 — 처음이니까요. 그런데 제품들이 쌓여서 이메일 클라이언트(email client)가 10만 개쯤 되면, 이제는 '이게 이메일 클라이언트로 인정받으려면' 꽤 잘 만들어져야 해요. 기준이 정말 높아지거든요.
text_zh: 我觉得吧，不管什么领域或者行业，越重要的东西，设计就越重要。一般来说，每当出现新的技术变革，比如移动互联网啊、web啊什么的，第一批产品其实不用设计得特别好，因为它们是第一个吃螃蟹的嘛。但是等到市面上有了十万个不同的邮箱客户端之后，现在随便哪个邮箱客户端都得做得相当不错，才能让人觉得这是个像样的邮箱。就是门槛已经被抬得特别高了。
text_es: Mi punto de vista es que, como en cualquier sector o industria, mientras más importante sea, más importa el diseño. Lo que pasa es que cada vez que surge un nuevo paradigma, no sé, como el móvil o la web o algo así, las primeras versiones de esos productos que aparecen no necesariamente tienen que estar súper bien diseñados porque son los primeros. Después, cuando ya tienes 100,000 clientes de email diferentes, cualquier cliente de email ahora tiene que estar bastante bueno para que siquiera lo consideren un cliente de email. Es como que el listón está altísimo.
context: Lenny asks Karri about when design can be enough of a differentiator against incumbents and whether founders should invest heavily in design versus other areas like distribution or technology. Karri explains his theory about how design becomes increasingly important as markets mature and become more crowded. He argues that in new paradigms like mobile or web, early products don't need great design since they're first to market, but as competition increases, the design bar rises significantly.
vocabulary_highlights: new paradigm, first iterations, the bar is so high

speaker: Karri Saarinen
text: I think today it's almost a very basic thing now. Pretty much from the very beginning, you need pretty high level design for people to even pay attention or consider you seriously. And I think it's not necessarily fair because sometimes it's like maybe the product is really good but they didn't have a designer or they didn't have time to do it and then people just dismiss it because it doesn't seem like something that they interest them.
text_ko: 요즘에는 그게 거의 기본이에요. 처음부터 사람들한테 주목받거나 진지하게 고려되려면 꽤 높은 수준의 하이레벨 디자인(high-level design)이 필요해요. 꼭 공평하다고는 할 수 없는데, 제품이 정말 좋은데도 디자이너가 없거나 디자인할 시간이 없어서 사람들이 관심을 안 가지면 그냥 무시당하곤 해요.
text_zh: 我觉得现在这基本上已经成了标配了。几乎从一开始，你就得有很高水准的设计，别人才会关注你，才会认真考虑你的产品。我觉得这不一定公平，因为有时候可能产品本身真的很不错，但他们没有设计师，或者没时间去做设计，结果大家就因为看起来不怎么样就直接pass了，觉得没什么意思。
text_es: Creo que hoy en día es algo súper básico ya. Prácticamente desde el inicio, necesitas un diseño de muy alto nivel para que la gente te haga caso o te tome en serio. Y pienso que no necesariamente es justo porque a veces puede ser que el producto esté padrísimo pero no tuvieron diseñador o no tuvieron tiempo para trabajarlo bien y entonces la gente lo descarta porque no parece algo que les llame la atención.
context: Karri continues explaining why design has become crucial for modern startups. He points out that unlike older companies like Google or YouTube that launched with very basic websites, today's startups need high-quality design from day one just to get noticed. He acknowledges this creates an unfair barrier where good products might be dismissed simply due to poor visual design, even when the underlying functionality is solid.
vocabulary_highlights: pay attention, consider you seriously, dismiss it

speaker: Karri Saarinen
text: So I think similarly, with startups or SaaS, it's like your landing page or some of the other things. It's like they are already communicating something to the user and they're setting the expectations and then I think that that can be very useful thing, especially early on when no one really knows you or knows the product or cares about you. So I think especially, I feel like design can be very good leverage in the beginning.
text_ko: 저도 비슷하게 생각해요. 스타트업(startups)이나 서비스형 소프트웨어(SaaS)에서는 랜딩 페이지(landing page)나 다른 몇 가지 요소들이 이미 사용자에게 무언가를 전달하고 기대치를 설정해요. 특히 아무도 아직 당신이나 제품을 잘 모르고 관심도 없을 초반에는 그게 훨씬 더 유용할 수 있어요. 그래서 저는 초반에 디자인이 정말 큰 레버리지(leverage)가 된다고 느껴요.
text_zh: 所以我觉得创业公司或者SaaS产品也是一样的道理，比如你的落地页(landing page)或者其他一些东西，它们其实已经在跟用户沟通了，在给用户设定期望值。我觉得这个特别有用，尤其是在早期阶段，那时候没人知道你是谁，不了解你的产品，也不关心你。所以我觉得设计在一开始的时候真的可以起到四两拨千斤的作用。
text_es: Entonces creo que pasa algo parecido con las startups o SaaS, es como tu página de aterrizaje (landing page) o algunas de las otras cosas. Es como que ya le están comunicando algo al usuario y están creando expectativas, y creo que eso puede ser súper útil, sobre todo al principio cuando nadie te conoce realmente o conoce el producto o le importas. Entonces creo que especialmente, siento que el diseño puede ser una palanca muy poderosa desde el comienzo.
context: Karri draws an analogy between product packaging (like Apple's attention to unboxing experiences) and startup design elements like landing pages. He explains that design serves as the first impression that sets user expectations before they even try the product. This is particularly valuable for unknown startups that need to establish credibility and quality perception from the first interaction, making design a powerful form of leverage in the early stages.
vocabulary_highlights: setting the expectations, very good leverage
topics: Product Management, Growth & Marketing, Starting a Company

speaker: Karri Saarinen
text: So for every project there's a project lead. That lead can be engineer or designer. It's not a formal role or it's not based on your whatever level or it's just like you need to be certain title that you can be that. It's more like an assignment that now you are responsible getting the project started and working together with the team, figuring it out, and then communicating changes or communicating how that progress happens.
text_ko: 그래서 모든 프로젝트에는 프로젝트 리드(project lead)가 있어요. 그 리드는 엔지니어나 디자이너일 수도 있어요. 이건 정식 직책이나 직급에 따라 정해지는 게 아니고, 꼭 특정 직함을 가져야만 맡을 수 있는 역할도 아니에요. 좀 더 정확히 말하면, 프로젝트를 시작하고 팀과 함께 방향을 잡아가며 문제를 해결하고, 진행 상황이나 변경 사항을 팀에 공유하는 책임을 맡는 배정이에요.
text_zh: 所以每个项目都有一个项目负责人(project lead)。这个负责人可以是工程师，也可以是设计师。这不是什么正式的职位，也不是看你什么级别，更不是说你必须有某个头衔才能当。就是个分工安排，现在你要负责把项目启动起来，跟团队一起合作，把事情搞定，然后有什么变化或者进展都要及时沟通。
text_es: Entonces para cada proyecto hay un líder de proyecto. Ese líder puede ser un ingeniero o un diseñador. No es un rol formal ni se basa en tu nivel o que necesites tener cierto título para poder serlo. Es más bien una asignación donde ahora tú eres el responsable de arrancar el proyecto y trabajar junto con el equipo, ir resolviendo las cosas sobre la marcha, y luego comunicar los cambios o comunicar cómo va avanzando todo.
context: Lenny asks how Linear functions with only one product manager across the entire company. Karri explains their project-based leadership model where engineers and designers take turns being project leads. This isn't a formal hierarchy based on seniority or titles, but rather a rotating assignment system where someone takes responsibility for driving a specific project forward, coordinating with the team, and managing communications about progress.
vocabulary_highlights: figuring it out, communicating changes

speaker: Karri Saarinen
text: I think sometimes people use data a lot or too much because they're worrying or they're afraid that, will I make the wrong choice? And I'm using data to make the choice for me. But then you might still feel like this is not the right choice, but the data is telling me is the right choice and then turns out maybe it was the right choice or not. But at least we made that choice and the data didn't make that choice for us.
text_ko: 가끔 사람들은 실수할까 봐, 잘못된 선택을 할까 봐 걱정해서 데이터(data)를 과하게 쓰는 것 같아요. 데이터를 통해 대신 선택해 주길 바라는 거죠. 그런데도 마음속으로는 '이게 진짜 맞는 선택일까' 하는 불안이 남을 수 있고, 데이터가 이게 맞다고 말해도 실제로는 맞을 수도 있고 아닐 수도 있어요. 그래도 적어도 그 선택은 우리가 한 거고, 데이터가 대신 한 건 아니에요.
text_zh: 我觉得有时候大家过度依赖数据，其实是因为担心害怕——怕做错决定对吧？就想着让数据来替我做选择。但问题是，即使数据显示这个选择是对的，你心里可能还是觉得不太对劲。最后不管结果怎么样，至少这个决定是我们自己做的，而不是被数据牵着鼻子走。
text_es: Creo que a veces la gente usa demasiados datos porque tiene miedo de equivocarse, ¿no? Como que dicen "ay, ¿y si tomo la decisión equivocada?" Entonces usan los datos para que básicamente los datos decidan por ellos. Pero después te puedes quedar con esa sensación de que no es la decisión correcta, aunque los datos te digan que sí lo es. Al final puede que haya sido la decisión acertada o no, pero lo importante es que nosotros tomamos esa decisión - no dejamos que los datos decidieran por nosotros.
context: Lenny asks about Linear's approach of not using metrics-based goals or A/B testing, which differs from many other companies. Karri explains his philosophy that over-reliance on data often stems from fear of making wrong decisions. He argues that leaders should make decisions based on customer understanding and intuition rather than letting data make choices for them, emphasizing the importance of taking ownership of decisions rather than hiding behind metrics.
topics: Decision Making, Leadership & Management, Product Management

speaker: Karri Saarinen
text: I think there's always things that you're supposed to do or it sounds like a good idea to do. And it could be like, yeah, come to this podcast. And I actually think before it wasn't like... Or I always have this question, is this important to do now or is it important to maybe do later? So I think, for example, the question on this podcast is I didn't feel like it was important to do it earlier because we weren't at the stage or a scale or something that I think it'd be as interesting or something.
text_ko: 항상 해야 할 일들이 있거나 그냥 좋은 생각처럼 들리는 일들이 있는 것 같아요. 예를 들어 '이 팟캐스트(podcast)에 나오면 좋겠다' 하는 얘기일 수도 있고요. 사실 전에는 꼭 그렇지 않았던 것 같아요. 저는 늘 '이걸 지금 하는 게 중요한가, 아니면 나중에 하는 게 더 나을까?'라는 질문을 해요. 그래서 이 팟캐스트의 경우를 예로 들면, 저는 예전에는 굳이 더 일찍 할 필요가 있다고 느끼지 않았어요. 그때는 우리가 아직 그런 단계에 있지 않았고 규모(scale)도 그만큼 크지 않아서 지금만큼 흥미롭지 않았을 거라고 생각했거든요.
text_zh: 我觉得总有一些事情，要么是你应该做的，要么听起来是个好主意。比如说，来参加这个播客。其实我以前不是这样想的...我总是在想一个问题，这件事是现在做重要，还是以后再做比较重要？拿这个播客来说吧，我之前觉得没必要这么早来做，因为我们还没到那个阶段，规模也不够，感觉不会那么有意思。
text_es: Creo que siempre hay cosas que se supone que debes hacer o que suenan como buena idea hacer. Y puede ser algo como, sí, ve a este podcast. Y la verdad es que antes no era como... O siempre me hago esta pregunta: ¿es importante hacer esto ahora o es importante hacerlo más adelante? Entonces creo que, por ejemplo, con el tema de este podcast, no sentía que fuera importante hacerlo antes porque no estábamos en la etapa o el nivel donde creo que hubiera sido tan interesante o algo así.
context: Lenny asks Karri about his exceptional focus and ability to avoid distractions, noting how difficult it was to get him on the podcast initially. Karri shares his decision-making framework for maintaining focus, explaining that he constantly evaluates whether activities are important to do now versus later. He uses the podcast example to illustrate how he delayed this interview until Linear reached a stage where the conversation would be more valuable and interesting.
vocabulary_highlights: you're supposed to do, sounds like a good idea

speaker: Katie Dill
text: The use of the word beauty in books that have been digitized by Google has decreased, like pretty dramatically. And it's aligned with this idea of, "Well, functionality is king. Functionality is what matters." As if people think about functionality and beauty as like two opposite things. No, they're not two opposite things. Functionality is important. And actually beauty enhances functionality because it does make things easier to use, more approachable, more compelling to use.
text_ko: 구글이 디지털화한 책들에서 'beauty'라는 단어 사용이 꽤 확 줄었어요. 그리고 이건 ‘기능성(functionality)이 최고다’라는 생각과 맞물려 있어요. 사람들은 기능성(functionality)과 아름다움(beauty)을 마치 서로 반대되는 것처럼 생각하는데, 전혀 그렇지 않아요. 기능성은 중요하지만, 사실 아름다움은 기능성을 더 잘 살려줘요 — 보기 좋으면 사용하기도 더 쉽고, 부담 없이 다가갈 수 있고, 더 쓰고 싶게 만들거든요.
text_zh: 在谷歌数字化的那些书里，"美"这个词的使用频率下降得特别厉害。这跟现在大家的想法很吻合，就是"功能为王，功能才是最重要的"。好像大家都觉得功能和美观是两个对立的东西。其实不是的，它们根本不对立。功能确实重要，但美观其实是能提升功能的，因为它真的能让东西更好用、更容易上手、更有吸引力。
text_es: Fíjate que el uso de la palabra "belleza" en los libros digitalizados por Google ha bajado muchísimo, de manera súper drástica. Y esto va de la mano con esa mentalidad de "bueno, la funcionalidad es lo que manda. La funcionalidad es lo único que importa." Como si la gente pensara que la funcionalidad y la belleza son dos cosas totalmente opuestas. No, para nada son opuestas. La funcionalidad es importante, claro. Pero la belleza en realidad potencia la funcionalidad porque hace que las cosas sean más fáciles de usar, más accesibles, más atractivas para el usuario.
context: Lenny asks Katie about the importance of beauty in product design and whether it's just subjective opinion or has objective value. Katie references research from Stefan Sagmeister and Jessica Walsh's book that shows the word "beauty" has declined in usage over the past 200 years as people have come to see functionality and beauty as opposing forces. Katie argues that this is a false dichotomy - functionality and beauty actually work together to create better user experiences.
vocabulary_highlights: pretty dramatically, as if, two opposite things, more compelling

speaker: Katie Dill
text: And the other piece of it that is not talked about in business as often is just the importance of how people feel. Things that are more beautiful, increase trust. You see that we've put painstaking detail into this, and we care about the details of how something works, and that gives you assurance that we care about other details that you can't see too.
text_ko: 비즈니스에서는 잘 얘기되지 않는 또 하나가 사람들이 어떻게 느끼는지의 중요성이에요. 보기 좋은 것들은 신뢰를 높여줘요. 여기에 얼마나 공들여 세심한 디테일을 담았는지를 보면 우리가 작동 방식 같은 세부사항까지 신경 쓴다는 걸 느끼게 되고, 그게 눈에 보이지 않는 다른 부분들도 신경 쓰고 있을 거라는 안심이 돼요.
text_zh: 还有一点在商界讨论得不够多的，就是人的感受有多重要。越美的东西，越能增加信任感。你看到我们在这上面下了很大功夫，我们很在意每个细节怎么呈现，这样你就能放心，那些你看不到的地方，我们同样也很用心。
text_es: Y la otra parte que no se menciona tanto en los negocios es simplemente lo importante que es cómo se siente la gente. Las cosas que son más hermosas generan más confianza. Cuando ves que le hemos puesto un cuidado extremo a los detalles, que nos importa cómo funciona cada cosa, eso te da la seguridad de que también nos preocupamos por otros detalles que no puedes ver.
context: Katie continues explaining why beauty matters in business products, particularly in B2B contexts. She argues that beautiful design signals quality and trustworthiness to users. When customers see that a company has invested painstaking effort in the visible details of their product, it creates confidence that the same level of care has been applied to the technical details they cannot see.
vocabulary_highlights: painstaking detail, gives you assurance

speaker: Katie Dill
text: The gravitational pull is to mediocrity. It is very easy to fall into a path of a baseline, where what is required to go to that next level where something feels truly great is certainly a lot of effort, and it's a concerted effort.
text_ko: 사람들은 평범함으로 끌리는 중력 같은 게 있어요. 기준선(baseline)에 머무는 길로 빠지는 건 정말 쉽고, 다음 단계로 올라가서 진짜 훌륭하다고 느껴질 수준에 닿으려면 확실히 많은 노력, 특히 의도적이고 집중적인 노력이 필요해요.
text_zh: 人都容易向平庸靠拢，这就像地心引力一样。很容易就走上了一条得过且过的路，但要想上一个台阶，做出真正出色的东西，那就需要付出很大的努力，而且必须是持续的、有目标的努力。
text_es: La tendencia natural es hacia la mediocridad. Es muy fácil caer en una zona de confort donde haces lo mínimo, y para llegar a ese siguiente nivel donde realmente sientes que algo está increíble, pues requiere mucho esfuerzo, y tiene que ser un esfuerzo constante y enfocado.
context: Lenny asks Katie about how teams can operationalize quality and maintain high design standards. Katie explains one of the core challenges in maintaining quality - that there's a natural tendency for teams and products to drift toward mediocre, baseline solutions because achieving true greatness requires sustained, coordinated effort from multiple people and teams working together intentionally.
vocabulary_highlights: gravitational pull, concerted effort

speaker: Katie Dill
text: Performance equals potential minus interference. And I really like this, it's pretty simple, but it's a good reminder that, as a leader, one of the things that you are of course driving towards is trying to get better performance so that your team feels more purpose and motivation and is excited about their work and that you're building greater things for your customers and you're having more business effect, and, of course, performance.
text_ko: 성과(Performance)는 잠재력(Potential)에서 방해(Interference)를 뺀 것이라고 해요. 저는 이 말이 정말 좋아요. 꽤 단순하지만, 리더로서 늘 떠올려야 할 좋은 리마인더예요. 리더로서 하는 일 중 하나는 성과를 끌어올려서 팀이 더 큰 목적의식과 동기부여를 느끼고 일에 열정을 갖게 하는 거예요. 그래야 고객을 위해 더 큰 가치를 만들고 비즈니스 효과(business effect)를 내고, 결국 성과(Performance)가 좋아지는 거죠.
text_zh: 表现等于潜力减去干扰因素。我特别认同这个观点，道理很简单，但很值得我们领导者时刻提醒自己——我们当然都在努力提升团队表现，让团队成员更有使命感和动力，对工作更有激情，这样才能为客户创造更大价值，产生更大的商业影响力，最终提升整体表现。
text_es: El rendimiento es igual al potencial menos las interferencias. Y esto me gusta mucho, es bastante sencillo, pero es un buen recordatorio de que, como líder, una de las cosas hacia las que obviamente te enfocas es tratar de conseguir mejor rendimiento para que tu equipo sienta más propósito y motivación, y se emocione con su trabajo, y para que estés construyendo cosas más grandes para tus clientes y tengas mayor impacto en el negocio, y, por supuesto, mejor rendimiento.
context: Lenny asks Katie about lessons she's learned from scaling design teams at multiple hypergrowth companies. Katie shares a formula she learned at Airbnb that has guided her leadership approach: Performance = Potential - Interference. She explains that leaders can improve team performance in two ways: increasing potential through hiring great people and developing talent, and decreasing interference by removing obstacles that prevent great people from doing their best work.
vocabulary_highlights: driving towards, business effect

speaker: Katie Dill
text: One of the biggest examples that I've seen of business impact through quality is actually in the checkout experience. We've done research on the checkout experience in some of the top e-commerce sites. We found that 99% of the top e-commerce sites have errors in their checkout flow that actually hinder more impactful, more seamless, quicker checkout, and therefore higher conversion with their customers.
text_ko: 제가 본 품질로 인한 비즈니스 영향 사례 중 하나는 바로 결제 경험(checkout experience)이에요. 상위 이커머스 사이트들(top e-commerce sites)의 결제 경험을 조사해보니, 상위 사이트의 99%가 결제 흐름(checkout flow)에 오류가 있어서 더 효과적이고 원활하며 빠른 결제를 방해하고, 결과적으로 더 높은 전환율(conversion)을 얻지 못하고 있더라고요.
text_zh: 我见过的质量对业务影响最大的例子，其实就是结账这个环节。我们研究了一些头部电商网站的结账体验，发现99%的顶级电商网站在结账流程(checkout flow)里都有问题，这些问题直接影响了用户体验，让结账变得不够顺畅、不够快，最终就是转化率(conversion)上不去。
text_es: Uno de los ejemplos más claros que he visto del impacto empresarial a través de la calidad es justamente en la experiencia de compra. Hemos hecho investigación sobre la experiencia de checkout en algunos de los sitios de e-commerce más importantes. Descubrimos que el 99% de los principales sitios de comercio electrónico tienen errores en su flujo de checkout que en realidad impiden una compra más fluida, más rápida y por lo tanto una mayor conversión con sus clientes.
context: Lenny asks Katie about making the ROI case for design quality versus just shipping new features quickly. Katie provides a concrete example from Stripe's work on checkout experiences. She explains that Stripe researched major e-commerce sites and discovered that nearly all of them had quality issues in their checkout flows that were actually hurting their business metrics. By fixing these design quality issues, businesses saw measurable improvements in conversion rates.
vocabulary_highlights: hinder, more seamless, higher conversion

speaker: Katie Dill
text: So I started to make pretty fast change and still moving in the direction that was necessary for the org to make the really large impact in how we were operating, but bringing folks along with me. You can inflict change on people, but if you want to do it with them trust is the key element there.
text_ko: 그래서 저는 꽤 빠르게 변화를 추진하기 시작했고, 조직(org)이 우리가 일하는 방식에 큰 임팩트를 주기 위해 필요한 방향으로 계속 움직였어요. 사람들을 동참시키면서요. 사람들에게 변화를 강제로 밀어붙일 수는 있지만, 그들과 함께 해내려면 신뢰(trust)가 핵심이에요.
text_zh: 所以我开始快速推进变革，还是朝着组织需要的方向走，要在运营方式上产生真正大的影响，但同时也要带着大家一起。你可以强加变革给别人，但如果你想和他们一起做，信任就是关键因素。
text_es: Entonces empecé a hacer cambios bastante rápidos pero siguiendo en la dirección que necesitaba la organización para lograr un impacto realmente grande en cómo estábamos operando, pero llevándome a la gente conmigo. Puedes imponerle cambios a la gente, pero si quieres hacerlo junto con ellos, la confianza es el elemento clave ahí.
context: Katie tells the story of when her design team at Airbnb staged an intervention because she hadn't earned their trust as a new leader. After receiving this difficult feedback, Katie learned that while she was making necessary changes to improve the organization, she was imposing changes on people rather than building trust first. She realized that effective change management requires bringing people along with you rather than forcing change upon them.
vocabulary_highlights: inflict change on people, bringing folks along with me

speaker: Kayvon Beykpour
text: When all the drama went down with Twitter and Elon ended up buying the company and after the eight months saga of legal back and forth ended up actually taking control of the company, there was that first two-day period where it was complete chaos at Twitter with the sink and Elon spreading his tentacles trying to find out who are the people that he wants to keep and what are the projects that are interesting.
text_ko: 트위터에서 온갖 드라마가 벌어지고 엘론이 결국 회사를 인수해서, 8개월에 걸친 법적 공방 끝에 실제로 경영권을 넘겨받았을 때요, 초반 이틀은 트위터가 완전 아수라장이었어요. 대규모 해고(sacking)가 일어나고 엘론은 여기저기 손을 뻗어 누구를 남기고 싶은지, 어떤 프로젝트가 남길 만한지 알아보느라 난리였어요.
text_zh: 当时推特那一堆破事闹得沸沸扬扬，马斯克最后还是把公司买下了，经过八个月的法律拉锯战，他真正接手了公司。刚开始那两天推特完全是一团乱麻，马斯克拿着水槽到处晃悠，同时开始摸底，看看哪些人值得留下，哪些项目有搞头。
text_es: Cuando se armó todo el drama con Twitter and Elon terminó comprando la empresa y después de ocho meses de idas y venidas legales finalmente tomó el control de la compañía, hubo esos primeros dos días donde fue un caos total en Twitter con lo del lavabo y Elon metiendo sus tentáculos por todas partes tratando de averiguar quiénes eran las personas que quería conservar y cuáles eran los proyectos que le interesaban.
context: Lenny asks Kayvon to share the story about getting Elon Musk up to speed at Twitter after the acquisition. Kayvon explains the chaotic first days after Elon took control of Twitter in October 2022, following an eight-month legal battle. During this period, Elon was trying to identify key personnel and interesting projects at the company. Scott Belsky had recommended that Elon speak with Kayvon, leading to their first meeting.
vocabulary_highlights: spreading his tentacles, saga of legal back and forth, complete chaos

speaker: Kayvon Beykpour
text: We wanted to change the lack of ambition, the lack of creativity, the lack of customers feeling that the product had changed at all. Because you would hear people, I mean, one of the beautiful things about working on Twitter as a product is that you have literally customers being injected into your veins.
text_ko: 우리는 야망도 부족하고 창의성도 부족한 데다 고객들이 제품이 전혀 달라졌다고 느끼지 못하는 그런 상태를 바꾸고 싶었어요. 왜냐하면 사람들 얘기를 실제로 들을 수 있거든요. 제 말은, 트위터(Twitter)라는 제품을 다루면서 일하는 멋진 점 중 하나는 고객들의 목소리가 말 그대로 우리에게 주입되는 느낌으로 계속 들어온다는 거예요.
text_zh: 我们想要改变这种缺乏野心、缺乏创新、还有用户感觉产品根本没什么变化的状况。因为你会听到用户的声音，我的意思是，做Twitter这个产品最棒的一点就是，用户的反馈简直就像直接注入你血管里一样。
text_es: Queríamos cambiar esa falta de ambición, esa falta de creatividad, y que los clientes sintieran que el producto no había evolucionado para nada. Porque escuchabas a la gente, o sea, una de las cosas más increíbles de trabajar en Twitter como producto es que literalmente tienes a los clientes metidos en las venas.
context: Lenny asks about how Kayvon transformed Twitter's product culture from stagnant to shipping regularly. Kayvon explains that while Twitter had successfully returned to user growth by 'refining the core' and optimizing existing features, this approach had made the organization risk-averse. He wanted to maintain that growth while also adding new capabilities and addressing customer complaints that the product hadn't meaningfully changed in years.
vocabulary_highlights: customers being injected into your veins

speaker: Kayvon Beykpour
text: I might flame out completely, but hell if I don't try. And so that was both fun and exhausting, like I said. But it was as simple as starting with we are voracious users of the product ourselves, and if we aren't, by the way, that's its own problem.
text_ko: 완전히 망해버릴지도 모르지만, 그래도 시도하지 않으면 안 되잖아요. 그래서 말했듯 그건 재밌기도 했고 정말 힘들기도 했어요. 근본은 단순했어요 — 우선 우리 스스로가 그 제품을 열성적으로 쓰는 사용자라는 것부터 출발한 거예요. 그리고 우리가 그렇지 않다면, 그 자체로 문제가 되는 거예요.
text_zh: 我可能会彻底搞砸，但不试试怎么知道呢。所以就像我说的，既有趣又累人。但其实道理很简单，就是从我们自己就是产品的重度用户开始，顺便说一句，如果我们自己都不用，那本身就是个问题。
text_es: Puede que fracase completamente, pero qué carajo, al menos lo voy a intentar. Y entonces fue divertido pero agotador a la vez, como te decía. Pero era tan simple como empezar con que nosotros somos usuarios voraces del producto, y si no lo somos, por cierto, eso ya es problema aparte.
context: Kayvon continues explaining his approach to transforming Twitter's product culture. He describes his mindset when taking on the challenge of making Twitter more innovative and ambitious. He emphasizes that the starting point was being passionate users of Twitter themselves, as he believes you need to be a customer of the product to build something wonderful. This was part of his strategy to identify pain points and build features they themselves wanted to use.
vocabulary_highlights: flame out completely, hell if I don't try, voracious users

speaker: Kayvon Beykpour
text: The sacred cows are like their own roadmap. What are all the things that you think we're not allowed to change? Let's start there. Everything from moving from reverse chron to a ranked feed, that was a sacred cow. Text and 140 characters, that's a sacred cow.
text_ko: 성역 같은 것들이 자기들만의 로드맵처럼 작동해요. 우리가 바꿀 수 없다고 생각하는 것들이 뭐가 있나요? 거기서부터 시작해요. 시간 역순 정렬(reverse chron)에서 순위형 피드(ranked feed)로 옮기는 것까지, 그게 다 성역이었어요. 텍스트와 140자 제한도 성역이었고요.
text_zh: 那些不能碰的东西其实就像是路线图一样。你觉得有哪些东西是我们不敢动的？咱们就从这儿开始。从时间倒序改成算法推荐，这就是个不能碰的东西。还有文字和140字符限制，这也是不能碰的。
text_es: Las vacas sagradas son como su propio mapa de ruta. ¿Cuáles son todas esas cosas que creemos que no podemos cambiar? Empecemos por ahí. Todo, desde cambiar del orden cronológico inverso a un feed rankeado (ranked feed), eso era una vaca sagrada. El texto y los 140 caracteres, esa es una vaca sagrada.
context: Kayvon explains his strategy for driving product innovation at Twitter. He describes how Twitter had many 'sacred cows' - long-held beliefs about things that couldn't be changed. Rather than seeing these as obstacles, he flipped the perspective and used them as a roadmap for potential improvements. These untouchable elements included the chronological timeline, the 140-character limit, and policies around user control over their reply spaces.
vocabulary_highlights: sacred cows

speaker: Kayvon Beykpour
text: I remember we had a PM on our team who was leading this feature who a few weeks into this project mentioned to me that she had had a conversation with someone on the engineering team that told them, 'Don't work on this feature. This is bad for your career. This is not going to launch, and you don't want to work on this. You don't want to be seen as having worked on this.'
text_ko: 기억나는 건, 우리 팀에 이 기능(feature)을 담당하던 PM(프로덕트 매니저)이 있었는데, 프로젝트 시작한 지 몇 주쯤 됐을 때 엔지니어링 팀(engineering team) 누군가랑 나눈 얘기를 저한테 들려줬어요. 그 사람이 그 PM에게 "이 기능 작업하지 마세요. 커리어에 안 좋아요. 이건 출시(launch)도 안 될 거예요. 이런 일에 관여하지 않는 게 좋아요. 이걸 작업한 사람으로 보이고 싶지 않을 거예요."라고 말했다고요.
text_zh: 我记得我们团队有个产品经理(PM)负责这个功能，项目进行了几周后她跟我说，有个工程师私下跟她聊天时说："别做这个功能了，对你职业发展不好。这东西根本上不了线，你最好别碰这个项目，也别让别人看到你参与过这个。"
text_es: Recuerdo que teníamos una PM en el equipo que estaba liderando esta funcionalidad y unas semanas después de empezar el proyecto me contó que alguien del equipo de ingeniería le había dicho: "No trabajes en esta feature. Esto te va a perjudicar profesionalmente. Esto no va a salir a producción, y no te conviene trabajar en esto. No querrás que te vean asociado con este proyecto."
context: Kayvon shares a specific example of Twitter's risk-averse culture while discussing the 'hide replies' feature. This feature would allow users to hide unwanted replies to their tweets, giving them more control over their reply space without impacting free speech. The story illustrates how deeply ingrained the resistance to change was at Twitter - an engineer actually advised a product manager not to work on the feature because it was seen as career-damaging to be associated with initiatives that challenged Twitter's established principles.
vocabulary_highlights: bad for your career

speaker: Kayvon Beykpour
text: One of the really important things about driving cultural change at the leadership level is you've got to identify whether someone's on the wagon or off the wagon and either quickly convince them to get on the wagon or if they're not on the wagon, they shouldn't be there.
text_ko: 리더십 차원에서 문화 변화를 이끌 때 정말 중요한 것 중 하나는 누가 변화에 동참하는 사람(on the wagon)이고 누가 동참하지 않는 사람(off the wagon)인지 빨리 가려내는 거예요. 동참하지 않은 사람은 빨리 설득해서 합류시키거나, 합류할 의지가 전혀 없다면 그 자리에 두면 안 돼요.
text_zh: 要在领导层推动文化变革，关键是要看清楚谁是支持的，谁是反对的。对于那些还在观望的人，你得赶紧把他们争取过来；如果有人就是不配合，那这个位置可能就不适合他了。
text_es: Una de las cosas realmente importantes para impulsar el cambio cultural desde el liderazgo es que tienes que identificar si alguien está alineado con la visión o no, y ya sea que los convenzas rápidamente de que se sumen al proyecto o, si no están dispuestos a hacerlo, pues simplemente no deberían estar ahí.
context: Lenny asks about the ingredients that helped turn around Twitter's product culture. Kayvon explains that after building momentum and telling a compelling vision story, team members would either be inspired by the new direction or remain pessimistic. He describes the critical need to determine who was aligned with the cultural change vision ('on the wagon') versus who wasn't, and to act accordingly. He admits Twitter was terrible at this and lacked the organizational structure to make swift decisions about team alignment.
vocabulary_highlights: on the wagon or off the wagon

speaker: Kayvon Beykpour
text: You need a special type of person to be able to both operate within the existing structure and change the structure, to know when to use the system and to know when to fuck the system. And I feel like my whole life has benefited from other people taking bets on me like that, to the point that even I was like, 'Really? You sure you want to?'
text_ko: 기존의 구조 안에서 잘 운영하면서도 그 구조를 바꿀 수 있는 특별한 사람이 필요해요. 시스템을 언제 활용해야 할지, 그리고 언제 시스템을 무시해야 할지를 아는 사람이죠. 제 인생은 다른 사람들이 저에게 그런 베팅을 해준 덕분에 많이 발전했어요. 가끔은 저도 '정말? 그렇게 하고 싶어?'라고 생각할 정도였죠.
text_zh: 你需要一种很特殊的人，既能在现有体系里好好干活，又能改变这个体系——知道什么时候要按规矩来，什么时候该打破规矩。我觉得我这辈子一直都在受益于别人对我的这种押注，甚至连我自己都会想："真的吗？你确定要这么做？"
text_es: Necesitas un tipo de persona muy especial que pueda trabajar dentro del sistema que ya existe y al mismo tiempo cambiarlo, que sepa cuándo seguir las reglas y cuándo mandar todo al carajo. Y siento que toda mi vida me he beneficiado de que otras personas apostaran por mí de esa manera, al punto que hasta yo mismo decía: "¿En serio? ¿Estás seguro de que quieres hacerlo?"
context: Kayvon explains Twitter's strategy of using small acquisitions and acquihires to drive cultural change and lead ambitious product initiatives. He describes how they would acquire founders and entrepreneurs to lead speculative bets like Spaces, Communities, and Community Notes (formerly Birdwatch). These leaders needed to balance entrepreneurial startup skills with the savviness to navigate a large organization. Kayvon reflects on how this strategy helped him personally, as he was a beneficiary of such a bet when Periscope was acquired.
vocabulary_highlights: fuck the system, taking bets on me

speaker: Jay Baxter
text: We actually look for agreement from people who have disagreed in the past. And what we see is when people actually have that sort of surprising agreement, that's what makes the notes so neutral and accurate and well- written, really, overall.
text_ko: 저희는 사실 과거에 반대했던 분들에게서도 동의를 구하려고 해요. 그리고 그런 분들이 의외로 합의할 때, 바로 그게 기록을 전반적으로 더 중립적이고 정확하며 잘 정리되게 해줘요.
text_zh: 我们其实专门找那些以前意见不合的人来达成共识。我们发现，当这些人能够出人意料地达成一致意见时，这样写出来的东西就会特别客观、准确，整体质量也特别高。
text_es: En realidad buscamos consenso entre personas que antes no estaban de acuerdo. Y lo que vemos es que cuando la gente llega a ese tipo de acuerdo inesperado, eso es lo que hace que las notas sean tan neutrales, precisas y bien redactadas en general.
context: Lenny asks Jay to explain how the Community Notes algorithm works. Community Notes is a system where users can add context to potentially misleading posts on X/Twitter. Jay explains that the key innovation isn't majority rule voting, but specifically looking for agreement between people who typically disagree with each other on topics, which they call a 'bridging-based algorithm.'
vocabulary_highlights: sort of surprising agreement, well-written, really, overall

speaker: Keith Coleman
speaker_expertise: Community Building, Data Analytics, Product Management
text: One philosophical thing that's important is that we want all of humanity to participate and sometimes people are surprised by that. We have all of humanity. We then have the data to understand what notes will be helpful to actual humanity.
text_ko: 중요한 철학적 관점 중 하나는 인류 전체가 참여하길 바란다는 거예요. 그 점에 깜짝 놀라는 분들도 가끔 있어요. 우리는 사실상 전 인류의 데이터를 가지고 있어서, 어떤 내용이 실제 사람들에게 도움이 될지 데이터로 이해할 수 있어요.
text_zh: 从理念上来说，很重要的一点就是我们希望全人类都能参与进来，有时候这会让人感到意外。我们有了全人类的参与，就有了数据来理解什么样的内容对真正的人类是有帮助的。
text_es: Una cosa filosófica que es importante es que queremos que toda la humanidad participe, y a veces la gente se sorprende por eso. Tenemos a toda la humanidad. Entonces tenemos los datos para entender qué información va a ser útil para la humanidad real.
context: Lenny asks Keith how they deal with very polarized users like anti-vaccine advocates or January 6th supporters. Keith explains their philosophy that Community Notes should be open to everyone, regardless of their views. He argues that having diverse participants, even with extreme viewpoints, actually helps the system better understand what information will be genuinely helpful to the broader population.
vocabulary_highlights: philosophical thing, actual humanity

speaker: Keith Coleman
speaker_expertise: Community Building, Data Analytics, Product Management
text: If I were to start a company in that company, it would be even leaner than I would've made it before. I've been amazed with just how much the team is able to accomplish with a small group and I think because of a small group-
text_ko: 사내에서 회사를 시작한다면, 예전에 제가 만들었을 때보다 훨씬 더 린(lean)하게 만들었을 거예요. 작은 인원으로도 팀이 이렇게 많은 걸 해내는 모습에 정말 놀랐고, 그게 소규모라서 가능한 것 같아요.
text_zh: 如果让我在那个公司里重新创业的话，我会做得比以前更精简。我真的很惊讶，就这么小的团队居然能搞定这么多事情，我觉得正是因为团队小——
text_es: Si tuviera que arrancar una empresa en ese sector, la haría aún más ágil de lo que la hubiera hecho antes. Me ha sorprendido increíblemente todo lo que el equipo logra conseguir siendo tan pocos, y creo que precisamente por ser un grupo pequeño-
context: Lenny asks Keith what might surprise people about working for Elon Musk within X. Keith shares how his experience at X has changed his perspective on team structure and company operations. He explains that seeing what small teams can accomplish has made him realize he would build future companies with even leaner teams than he previously thought possible.
vocabulary_highlights: even leaner, small group

speaker: Jay Baxter
text: There have been external studies run by people totally independent of us who have found that if you take a post with or without a Community Note, that actually people's agreement with the core claims in the post does change if they see it with a note versus without.
text_ko: 저희와 전혀 관련 없는 외부 연구에서, 커뮤니티 노트(Community Note)가 있는 게시물과 없는 게시물을 비교해 보니 사람들이 그 게시물의 핵심 주장에 동의하는 정도가 실제로 달라진다고 밝혀졌어요.
text_zh: 有一些完全独立的第三方研究发现，如果你拿同一条帖子，一个版本带社区笔记(Community Note)，一个版本不带，用户看到带笔记的版本时，对帖子核心观点的认同度确实会发生变化。
text_es: Ha habido estudios externos realizados por gente completamente independiente a nosotros que han encontrado que si tomas una publicación con o sin una Nota Comunitaria (Community Note), efectivamente el nivel de acuerdo de las personas con las afirmaciones principales del post sí cambia cuando la ven con la nota versus sin ella.
context: Jay is explaining the effectiveness of Community Notes in response to Lenny's question about dealing with polarized users. He's addressing the concern that fact-checking might not actually change people's minds about controversial topics. Jay cites independent research showing that Community Notes do measurably impact how much people agree with claims in posts when they see additional context versus when they don't.
vocabulary_highlights: totally independent of us, core claims, versus without

speaker: Jay Baxter
text: I think the key thing, really, that we do is we actually look for agreement from people who have disagreed in the past. And what we see is when people actually have that sort of surprising agreement, that's what makes the notes so neutral and accurate and well-written, really, overall.
text_ko: 정말 핵심은 저희가 하는 일이 과거에 의견이 달랐던 사람들에게서 합의를 찾아보는 거예요. 사람들이 의외로 합의를 이루면 그게 메모를 전반적으로 훨씬 더 중립적이고 정확하며 잘 작성되게 해요.
text_zh: 我觉得关键在于，我们其实专门去找那些以前意见不合的人，看他们能不能达成一致。我们发现，当这些人真的能出人意料地取得共识时，这样写出来的notes就特别中性、准确，整体质量也特别高。
text_es: Yo creo que lo clave de lo que hacemos es que realmente buscamos consenso entre personas que antes no estaban de acuerdo. Y lo que vemos es que cuando la gente llega a ese tipo de acuerdo inesperado, eso es lo que hace que las notas sean tan neutrales, precisas y bien redactadas en general.
context: Lenny asks for a deeper understanding of how the Community Notes algorithm works, noting that it's absurd that it works at all. Jay explains that many people misunderstand the system, thinking it's either immediate posting or simple majority voting. He clarifies that the key innovation is their 'bridging-based agreement algorithm' that specifically seeks consensus between users who typically disagree with each other.
vocabulary_highlights: key thing, really, sort of surprising agreement, well-written, really, overall

speaker: Keith Coleman
speaker_expertise: Community Building, Data Analytics, Product Management
text: Every post is eligible for notes. We shouldn't exempt Elon. We shouldn't exempt government figures. We should be like everyone... Even advertisers can get notes.
text_ko: 모든 게시물(post)은 노트(notes) 대상이에요. 일론 머스크(Elon Musk)라고 해서 예외로 해선 안 되고, 정부 인사(government figures)도 예외로 해선 안 돼요. 모두에게 똑같이 적용해야 해요. 광고주(advertisers)도 노트를 받을 수 있어야 해요.
text_zh: 每条推文都可以被加注释，马斯克也不例外，政府官员也不例外。咱们应该一视同仁...连广告主的内容都能被加注释。
text_es: Cualquier publicación puede recibir notas. No deberíamos hacer excepciones con Elon. No deberíamos hacer excepciones con figuras del gobierno. Deberíamos tratarlos como a cualquier otro... Incluso los anunciantes pueden recibir notas.
context: Lenny asks when a post gets triggered for Community Notes consideration - whether there's a threshold or if anyone can write notes on anything. Keith explains one of their core principles: that Community Notes applies universally to all content on the platform without exceptions. This includes posts from world leaders, Elon Musk himself, government officials, and even advertisements, ensuring an 'even playing field' for information accuracy.
vocabulary_highlights: exempt, even playing field

speaker: Keith Coleman
speaker_expertise: Community Building, Data Analytics, Product Management
text: We try to make notes as fast as we can, so we want them to appear instantly if possible. But inevitably, there's going to be a time gap between when a post goes live and when people figure out what's going on and when they get the note out there.
text_ko: 우리는 가능한 한 빨리 노트를 만들려고 해서, 가능하면 즉시 보이길 원해요. 하지만 글이 공개되는 시점과 사람들이 상황을 파악해서 노트를 올리는 시점 사이에는 어쩔 수 없이 시간 차가 생겨요.
text_zh: 我们尽量快速地做笔记，最好能做到即时显示。但不可避免的是，从帖子发布到大家搞清楚情况再到把笔记发出来，这中间肯定会有个时间差。
text_es: Tratamos de crear las notas lo más rápido posible, así que queremos que aparezcan al instante si se puede. Pero inevitablemente va a haber un desfase entre cuando se publica un post y cuando la gente se da cuenta de lo que está pasando y cuando logran sacar la nota.
context: Lenny mentions loving the feature where users get notified if they liked a post that later received a Community Note, so they don't remember false information. Keith explains their approach to timing - while they aim for instant notes, there's always a delay between when misleading content is posted and when the community can research, write, and approve corrective context through their consensus process.
vocabulary_highlights: inevitably, time gap, figure out what's going on

speaker: Keith Yandell
text: Every business that you have heard of has gotten rejected by at least a handful of venture capitalists at one point or another. And so that drive to keep going if you believe in the business is critical, absolutely critical. I mean, we were weeks of runway situation and had been told no by everyone. And it was just Tony's drive, really, to keep going.
text_ko: 여러분이 들어본 거의 모든 사업은 적어도 몇몇 벤처 투자자들(venture capitalists)에게 한 번쯤은 거절을 당했어요. 그래서 사업을 믿는다면 계속 밀고 나가려는 그 의지는 정말 중요해요, 절대적으로 중요해요. 제 말은, 저희는 런웨이(runway)가 몇 주밖에 남지 않은 상황이었고 모두에게서 '안 된다'는 말을 들었어요. 결국 계속할 수 있게 한 건 진짜로 토니의 그 의지였어요.
text_zh: 你听说过的每家公司，基本上都被风投(venture capitalists)拒绝过好多次，这很正常。所以如果你真的看好这个生意，那种坚持下去的劲头就太关键了，真的特别关键。我们当时账上的钱只够撑几个星期了，所有人都跟我们说不行，就是托尼那股不服输的劲儿，硬是要继续干下去。
text_es: Todos los negocios que conoces han sido rechazados por al menos varios capitalistas de riesgo en algún momento. Y por eso esa determinación de seguir adelante cuando crees en tu empresa es fundamental, absolutamente fundamental. O sea, estábamos a semanas de quedarnos sin dinero y todo el mundo nos había dicho que no. Y fue realmente la determinación de Tony, su empeño, lo que nos hizo seguir.
context: Lenny asks Keith about advice for founders going through tough fundraising periods. Keith reflects on DoorDash's difficult Series D funding round, when they had very little runway left and had been rejected by numerous venture capitalists. He emphasizes that rejection is universal among successful businesses and shares how Tony Xu's persistence was crucial during their near-bankruptcy situation.
vocabulary_highlights: handful of, weeks of runway situation, drive to keep going

speaker: Keith Yandell
text: And for me, one of the top things I always hear about DoorDash from an executive standpoint when we do the internal survey is it's a "no politics, no asshole" culture. And I'm not one to swear a lot, but after interviewing Ryan Sokol, who's now our VP of eng, he was just kind of aloof. He came off as aloof to me, really curt answers.
text_ko: 제 경우엔 임원 대상 내부 설문을 하면 DoorDash에 대해 항상 가장 많이 듣는 얘기 중 하나가 '정치질 없음, 무례한 사람 없음' 문화예요. 저는 욕을 자주 하는 편은 아닌데, 지금은 우리 엔지니어링 부사장(VP of Engineering)이 된 라이언 소콜을 인터뷰했을 때 그는 좀 쌀쌀맞게 느껴졌어요. 제게는 무심하고 답변도 되게 짧고 퉁명스러웠어요.
text_zh: 对我来说，每次我们做内部调研的时候，高管们对DoorDash评价最高的一点就是我们是"不搞政治，不要混蛋"的企业文化。我平时不怎么爆粗口，但是当时面试Ryan Sokol的时候——他现在是我们的工程副总裁——他给我的感觉就是很冷淡，回答问题特别简短生硬。
text_es: Y para mí, una de las cosas que más escucho sobre DoorDash desde el punto de vista ejecutivo cuando hacemos la encuesta interna es que tenemos una cultura de "nada de política, nada de cabrones". Y no soy de andar diciendo groserías, pero después de entrevistar a Ryan Sokol, que ahora es nuestro VP de ingeniería, se veía medio distante. Me pareció distante, con respuestas muy secas.
context: Lenny asks Keith about a story where he called a candidate an "asshole" during the interview process. Keith explains DoorDash's "no politics, no asshole" culture and describes how Ryan Sokol, who is now their VP of engineering, initially came across as aloof and gave curt answers during his interview, which made Keith concerned about cultural fit.
vocabulary_highlights: from an executive standpoint, kind of aloof, came off as aloof, really curt answers

speaker: Keith Yandell
text: And six months later, he told me that one of the reasons why he joined DoorDash was that we were going to blackball him potentially from joining just because of his attitude, because his perspective is life's too short to work with people you don't really enjoy, and a lot of people pay lip service.
text_ko: 그리고 6개월 뒤 그는 DoorDash에 합류한 이유 중 하나가 우리가 그의 태도 때문에 그를 블랙볼(blackball)해서 못 들어오게 할 수도 있었기 때문이라고 말했어요. 그의 관점은 ‘같이 일하는 사람이 마음에 들지 않으면 인생이 너무 짧다’였고, 많은 사람들은 그런 말을 입으로만 한다고요.
text_zh: 六个月后，他跟我说，他之所以决定加入DoorDash，其中一个原因就是我们差点因为他的态度问题把他拉黑了。他的想法很简单——人生苦短，干嘛要跟自己不喜欢的人共事呢？而且现在很多人都是嘴上说说而已，光说不做。
text_es: Y seis meses después me dijo que una de las razones por las que se unió a DoorDash fue que íbamos a vetarlo potencialmente, a ponerlo en la lista negra para que no se uniera, solo por su actitud, porque su perspectiva es que la vida es muy corta para trabajar con gente que realmente no disfrutas, y mucha gente solo habla de dientes para afuera.
context: Keith continues the story about Ryan Sokol's hiring process. After having dinner and addressing the cultural concerns directly, Ryan later explained that DoorDash's willingness to potentially reject a qualified candidate solely based on attitude actually convinced him to join. This demonstrated to Ryan that the company genuinely prioritized cultural fit over just technical qualifications.
vocabulary_highlights: blackball him potentially, pay lip service

speaker: Keith Yandell
text: If you want to achieve a 10x outcome, hiring someone that's an expert in the field, it's maybe unlikely you're going to achieve that 10x outcome, because they're likely to do things the way things have always been done. So you might achieve incremental benefits, but the odds of completely reinventing the system and doing something that's vastly superior to others is much lower.
text_ko: 만약 10배 성과(10x outcome)를 내고 싶다면, 그 분야의 전문가를 데려온다고 해서 그 목표를 달성할 가능성은 오히려 낮아요. 전문가들은 대개 기존 하던 방식대로 일하는 경향이 있어서요. 그래서 어느 정도의 점진적 개선(incremental benefits)은 얻을 수 있지만, 시스템을 완전히 재창조해서 남들보다 훨씬 뛰어난 결과를 만들 가능성은 훨씬 낮아요.
text_zh: 如果你想实现10倍的成果，雇个这个领域的专家，可能反而达不到10倍的效果，因为他们很可能还是按老套路来做事。这样你最多就是小有改进，但要想彻底颠覆现有体系、做出远超别人的东西，可能性就小多了。
text_es: Si quieres lograr resultados 10 veces mejores, contratar a alguien que sea experto en el área probablemente no te va a dar ese resultado exponencial, porque seguramente va a hacer las cosas como siempre se han hecho. Tal vez consigas mejoras graduales, pero las posibilidades de reinventar completamente el sistema y hacer algo que sea muchísimo mejor que lo de otros son mucho menores.
context: Lenny asks Keith how he's able to credibly lead teams in areas where he lacks expertise. Keith explains Tony Xu's philosophy from the book "Range" about why generalists can be better than specialists. He describes how Tony deliberately puts people in roles outside their expertise area because domain experts tend to stick to conventional approaches, while outsiders are more likely to completely reimagine systems and achieve breakthrough results.
vocabulary_highlights: 10x outcome, incremental benefits, vastly superior

speaker: Keith Yandell
text: And I think it's a big part of our success, is this desire to be successful, regardless of who's in charge.
