And that comes from the fact when I joined DoorDash, we were getting our tails kicked. We were in fourth place in the space. Uber had just launched food and rocket to market share leadership.
text_ko: 그리고 우리 성공의 큰 요인 중 하나는 누가 책임자든 상관없이 성공하고자 하는 그 열망이에요. 제가 DoorDash에 합류했을 때 우리는 완전히 밀리고 있었어요. 업계에서 4위였고, Uber는 막 음식 배달 서비스를 시작해서 시장 점유율 선두(market share leadership)로 치고 올라갔죠.
text_zh: 我觉得这是我们成功的一个重要原因，就是不管谁当老大，我们都有这种强烈的成功欲望。这其实源于我刚加入DoorDash的时候，我们被打得挺惨的，在这个赛道里排第四。Uber刚推出外卖业务就迅速抢占了市场份额的领导地位。
text_es: Y creo que es una gran parte de nuestro éxito, esta gana de triunfar, sin importar quién esté al mando. Y eso viene del hecho de que cuando me uní a DoorDash, nos estaban dando una paliza. Estábamos en cuarto lugar en el sector. Uber acababa de lanzar comida y se disparó al liderazgo del mercado.
context: Keith discusses his philosophy of hiring people better than himself and then getting out of their way as they succeed. He explains how this collaborative mindset became part of DoorDash's DNA because when he joined, the company was struggling badly - they were in fourth place in food delivery and Uber had just entered the market and quickly gained leadership position.
vocabulary_highlights: getting our tails kicked, rocket to market share leadership

speaker: Keith Yandell
text: And so one thing I noticed is, it's hard to come into a place and be new and understand how things work and what it means to be successful there. And so the idea was to do our best to scale that. And one thing that Tony taught me is one thing that scales really well is written work.
text_ko: 한 가지 느낀 건, 새로 들어가서 그 조직이 어떻게 돌아가는지, 거기서 성공한다는 게 뭔지 파악하기가 쉽지 않다는 거예요. 그래서 그걸 최대한 확장(scale)하려고 했어요. 토니가 가르쳐 준 한 가지는 서면 작업(written work)이 정말 잘 확장(scale)된다는 점이에요.
text_zh: 我发现啊，刚到一个新地方，要搞清楚这里怎么运作、怎样才算成功，真的挺难的。所以我们就想着怎么把这个经验复制推广出去。Tony跟我说过一句话，最容易规模化的就是书面的东西。
text_es: Y entonces algo que me di cuenta es que es súper difícil llegar a un lugar nuevo y entender cómo funcionan las cosas ahí y qué significa tener éxito en ese lugar. Entonces la idea era hacer nuestro mejor esfuerzo para escalar eso. Y algo que Tony me enseñó es que algo que escala muy bien es el trabajo escrito.
context: Lenny asks Keith about his "How to work with Keith" document that he created for his teams. Keith explains that as DoorDash was growing rapidly (2-3x headcount each year), it became difficult to scale culture and help new employees understand how to be successful. Tony Xu taught him that written documentation is one of the most effective ways to scale knowledge and culture across a fast-growing organization.
vocabulary_highlights: scale that, scales really well

speaker: Keith Yandell
text: And so now if I get a blind reference, people are going to hear that, "It's not all about the company. It's not all about Keith. It's about you and your career," and that's going to pay back 10x. Maybe you lose one really talented person, but they probably shouldn't be there anyway. They're probably going to leave anyway.
text_ko: 그래서 이제 만약 제가 블라인드 레퍼런스(blind reference)를 받으면, 사람들은 "회사가 전부가 아니고, Keith 얘기도 아니고, 이건 당신과 당신의 커리어에 관한 거예요"라고 들을 거예요. 그게 10배로 돌아와요. 어쩌면 정말 재능 있는 한 명을 잃을 수도 있지만, 그런 사람은 애초에 거기 있어야 할 사람이 아닐 가능성이 크고요. 어차피 떠날 사람일 테니까요.
text_zh: 所以现在如果有人私下打听我的口碑，别人会说"他不是只顾着公司利益，也不是只为了Keith自己，而是真心为你的职业发展着想"，这种口碑会给你带来10倍的回报。也许你会失去一个很有才华的人，但这种人本来就不适合待在这里，反正迟早也会走的。
text_es: Y entonces ahora, si alguien pide referencias sobre mí sin que yo sepa, la gente va a escuchar que "no se trata solo de la empresa, no se trata solo de Keith, se trata de ti y de tu carrera," y eso te va a regresar multiplicado por diez. Tal vez pierdas a una persona muy talentosa, pero probablemente no debería estar ahí de todas formas. De todas maneras probablemente se iba a ir.
context: Keith explains his philosophy of helping employees find their next job, even if it's outside DoorDash. He describes the long-term benefits of this approach - when people do reference checks on him as a manager, they hear that he puts employees' career interests first. This reputation pays dividends in attracting talent, even if it occasionally means losing someone who would have left eventually anyway.
vocabulary_highlights: blind reference, pay back 10x

speaker: Ken Norton
speaker_expertise: Executive Coaching, Product Management, Career Development
text: Part of what I think is pretty exciting about product management is you are a leader from day one in product management. There's leadership all over the place, but that's your job. You're a leader. You don't have any formal authority, but you're a leader. You're expected to lead.
text_ko: 제가 생각하기에 프로덕트 매니지먼트(product management)의 가장 흥미로운 점 중 하나는 처음부터 리더라는 거예요. 리더십은 조직 곳곳에 있지만, 그 역할이 바로 당신에게 주어져 있어요. 공식적인 권한이 없을 수도 있지만 그래도 리더로서 이끌어야 한다고 기대받아요.
text_zh: 我觉得产品管理(product management)特别有意思的一点就是，你从第一天开始就得当领导。虽然到处都有各种领导，但这就是你的活儿——你就是个领导。你手里没什么实权，但你就得起到领导作用，大家就指望你来带头。
text_es: Una de las cosas que me parece súper emocionante de la gestión de productos es que desde el primer día ya eres líder. Hay liderazgo por todos lados, pero ese es tu trabajo. Eres líder. No tienes autoridad formal, pero eres líder. Se espera que lideres.
context: This quote appears at the very beginning of the episode as Ken introduces the foundational challenge of product management. Ken is establishing the core tension that product managers face throughout their careers - they must lead and influence without traditional hierarchical power. This sets up one of his key themes about why product management is such excellent training for executive leadership roles.
vocabulary_highlights: formal authority

speaker: Ken Norton
speaker_expertise: Executive Coaching, Product Management, Career Development
text: I started to simultaneously recognize the shortcomings of giving advice, because it seemed like, well, I can meet with these folks, I could tell them what I did, I could tell them what Google did, and that'll answer all their questions. You start to realize advice is not as powerful as you might think it is. It's a little bit like cotton candy.
text_ko: 저는 동시에 조언하는 것의 한계도 느끼기 시작했어요. 사람들을 만나서 제가 했던 방식이나 구글이 했던 걸 얘기해주면 그들의 모든 질문이 해결될 것 같았는데, 조언이 생각만큼 힘이 세지 않다는 걸 깨닫게 됐어요. 약간 솜사탕 같아요.
text_zh: 我开始同时意识到给建议这事儿的局限性，因为感觉就是，我可以和这些人见面，可以告诉他们我是怎么做的，可以告诉他们谷歌是怎么做的，这样就能解决他们所有问题了。但你慢慢发现，建议其实没有你想象的那么有用。有点像棉花糖一样，看起来挺大一团，其实没什么实质内容。
text_es: Empecé a darme cuenta de las limitaciones que tiene dar consejos, porque pensaba: "Bueno, puedo reunirme con esta gente, les cuento lo que hice yo, les cuento lo que hizo Google, y eso va a resolver todas sus dudas." Te das cuenta de que los consejos no son tan poderosos como uno cree. Es como el algodón de azúcar.
context: Lenny asks Ken how he transitioned from being a Google executive to becoming a full-time executive coach. Ken explains his realization while working at Google Ventures that traditional advice-giving has significant limitations. He discovered that simply telling portfolio founders what worked at Google wasn't effective because it lacked context for their specific situations, leading him to discover the power of coaching over mentoring.
vocabulary_highlights: shortcomings, cotton candy

speaker: Ken Norton
speaker_expertise: Executive Coaching, Product Management, Career Development
text: There's a sense of what got me here isn't going to get me there. That's oftentimes when they reach out for coaching. I think my clients are also very introspective and surrounded by great mentors and advisors and have all sorts of people in their life who can help them, but are realizing that a lot of the work is going to be internal work that's going to get them to the next level.
text_ko: 여기까지 데려다 준 방식으론 앞으로는 안 될 것 같다는 느낌이 들어요. 그럴 때 코칭(coaching)을 찾으시는 경우가 많죠. 제 고객분들도 스스로를 많이 돌아보는 편이고 훌륭한 멘토와 조언자들로 둘러싸여 있어서 도와줄 사람이 많은데, 결국 다음 단계로 가려면 많은 부분이 내면의 작업(internal work)이라는 걸 깨닫고 계세요.
text_zh: 有种感觉就是，过去让我成功的那套东西，未来可能就不管用了。通常这个时候他们就会找教练。我觉得我的客户都挺会自我反思的，身边也有很多优秀的导师和顾问，生活中不缺能帮到他们的人，但他们意识到，要想更上一层楼，很多功夫其实得在自己身上下，得做内在的修炼。
text_es: Hay una sensación de que lo que me trajo hasta aquí no me va a llevar hasta allá. Ahí es cuando muchas veces buscan coaching. Creo que mis clientes también son muy introspectivos y están rodeados de excelentes mentores y asesores, tienen todo tipo de gente en su vida que los puede ayudar, pero se dan cuenta de que gran parte del trabajo va a ser trabajo interno lo que los va a llevar al siguiente nivel.
context: Lenny asks Ken what types of clients he works with and when people typically come to him for coaching. Ken explains that his clients are usually senior product leaders (CPOs, VPs of product) who are facing career milestones or transitions. These leaders have already mastered the technical aspects of their roles but recognize they need to do deeper personal development work to reach the next level of effectiveness.
vocabulary_highlights: what got me here isn't going to get me there, very introspective, internal work
topics: Coaching & Development, Career Development, Leadership & Management

speaker: Ken Norton
speaker_expertise: Executive Coaching, Product Management, Career Development
text: But then suddenly you're put in a place where you realize that the rules of the game aren't so black and white. Maybe there's a long delay now between when you get to see what you did and the score of it. Things start to behave in unexpected ways. The most frightening part about it is you look around and everyone is looking at you like you're the designer of the game, and you thought you were playing.
text_ko: 그런데 어느 순간 갑자기 게임의 규칙이 그렇게 단순히 흑백논리로 설명할 수 없다는 걸 깨닫게 되는 상황에 놓여요. 자기가 한 일과 그에 대한 평가(score)를 확인하는 사이에 긴 지연이 생길 수 있어요. 일들이 예기치 않게 돌아가기 시작해요. 가장 무서운 건 둘러보면 모두가 당신을 게임의 설계자인 것처럼 쳐다보는데, 당신은 그저 게임을 하고 있다고 생각하고 있었다는 거예요.
text_zh: 但突然间你发现，游戏规则其实没那么非黑即白。可能现在你做了什么事情，要等很久才能看到结果和反馈。事情开始变得出人意料。最可怕的是，你环顾四周，发现所有人都在看着你，好像你就是游戏规则的制定者一样，可你以为自己只是个玩家而已。
text_es: Pero de repente te encuentras en una situación donde te das cuenta de que las reglas del juego no son tan claras como pensabas. A lo mejor ahora hay un retraso enorme entre cuando haces algo y cuando ves los resultados. Las cosas empiezan a comportarse de maneras que no esperabas. Y lo que más miedo da es cuando volteas a ver a tu alrededor y todos te están viendo como si fueras tú quien diseñó el juego, cuando en realidad pensabas que solo estabas jugando.
context: Ken is using a video game analogy to explain the transition from individual contributor to senior leader. He describes how early career feels like learning to play a structured game with clear rules and immediate feedback, but senior leadership roles are much more ambiguous. The transition is jarring because suddenly others expect you to set the rules rather than just follow them, which requires a fundamental mindset shift.
vocabulary_highlights: black and white, long delay, designer of the game

speaker: Ken Norton
speaker_expertise: Executive Coaching, Product Management, Career Development
text: Are you responding to the world from a place of fear, where you see problems and threats, you want to be right, you want to be liked, you're defensive as an inward approach, or are you responding to the world from a place of openness, possibility, curiosity, passion, growth, purpose?
text_ko: 세상에 반응할 때 두려움에서 출발해서 문제와 위협만 보고, 옳으려고 하고 사람들에게 잘 보이고 싶어하며 방어적으로 반응하세요? 아니면 마음을 열고 가능성을 보며 호기심과 열정, 성장과 목적 의식으로 반응하세요?
text_zh: 你面对这个世界的时候，是带着恐惧心理吗？总是看到问题和威胁，想要证明自己是对的，想要被人喜欢，处处防备，什么都往内收？还是说你是以开放的心态面对世界，看到各种可能性，保持好奇心，充满激情，追求成长和目标？
text_es: ¿Estás reaccionando al mundo desde el miedo, donde solo ves problemas y amenazas, donde quieres tener la razón, quieres caer bien, te pones a la defensiva con una mentalidad cerrada, o estás respondiendo al mundo desde la apertura, las posibilidades, la curiosidad, la pasión, el crecimiento y el propósito?
context: Lenny asks Ken about a key concept he's been developing around leadership mindset shifts. Ken explains his framework of 'creative versus reactive' leadership, which distinguishes between two fundamental ways leaders can approach challenges. This framework, adapted from various leadership theories, identifies whether leaders operate from fear and defensiveness (reactive) or from openness and possibility (creative).
vocabulary_highlights: place of fear, inward approach, place of openness

speaker: Ken Norton
speaker_expertise: Executive Coaching, Product Management, Career Development
text: For me, the key to that was letting go of needing to be liked and redefining it as an admiration that takes place over time. So rather than I want to leave this room with everyone liking me, I started to realize I want to be the type of leader where, a decade later, people say, 'I would work with that guy again in a heartbeat.'
text_ko: 저에게 그 핵심은 '호감을 얻어야 한다'는 집착을 내려놓고, 그걸 시간이 흐르며 쌓이는 존경으로 재정의한 거예요. 그래서 '지금 이 방을 나갈 때 모두가 나를 좋아했으면 좋겠다'가 아니라, '10년 뒤에도 사람들이 "그 사람과 주저 없이 다시 일하겠다"고 말하는 그런 리더가 되고 싶다'는 걸 깨달았어요.
text_zh: 对我来说，关键是要放下那种"必须被人喜欢"的想法，把它重新定义为一种需要时间积累的敬佩。所以我不再想着"离开这个房间时每个人都得喜欢我"，而是开始意识到，我要做那种十年后别人会说"我绝对愿意再和那家伙合作"的领导者。
text_es: Para mí, la clave estuvo en dejar de necesitar que me cayera bien a todo el mundo y redefinirlo como una admiración que se construye con el tiempo. En lugar de pensar "quiero salir de esta reunión cayéndole bien a todos", empecé a darme cuenta de que quería ser el tipo de líder del que, diez años después, la gente dijera: "Con ese tipo trabajaría otra vez sin dudarlo."
context: Lenny asks Ken for specific advice on how to shift from the reactive 'need to be liked' mindset to a more creative leadership approach. Ken shares his personal transformation from seeking immediate approval to focusing on long-term respect and admiration. This represents his shift from reactive leadership (needing instant validation) to creative leadership (operating from purpose and long-term vision).
vocabulary_highlights: letting go of, redefining it as, in a heartbeat

speaker: Ken Norton
speaker_expertise: Executive Coaching, Product Management, Career Development
text: I think probably the number one category, I'm not sure it's necessarily a problem, but maybe category or problems, is how much all of the challenges that senior executives are dealing with come down to people versus product. So it's like it's fun to think about designing products, optimizing, doing user discovery, and testing what, but it's like you sit down with an executive and it's all about people.
text_ko: 제 생각엔 아마도 가장 큰 범주(문제인지 정확하진 않지만)는 고위 임원들(senior executives)이 다루는 거의 모든 과제가 제품(product)보다 사람 문제로 귀결된다는 점이에요. 제품(product)을 설계하고 최적화하고 유저 디스커버리(user discovery)나 테스트(testing)를 해보는 건 재밌지만, 막상 임원과 마주 앉아 보면 결국 다 사람 얘기예요.
text_zh: 我觉得可能最主要的一个方面吧，我不确定这算不算问题，但可能是最大的问题或者说挑战，就是高管们面临的所有难题，归根结底都是人的问题而不是产品问题。就是说，设计产品啊、做优化啊、用户调研啊、测试什么的，这些听起来都挺有意思的，但是你真的坐下来跟高管聊的时候，发现讨论的全都是人的事儿。
text_es: Creo que probablemente la categoría número uno, no estoy seguro de que sea necesariamente un problema, pero tal vez la categoría de problemas más importante, es qué tanto todos los desafíos que enfrentan los altos ejecutivos se reducen a temas de personas versus producto. O sea, está padrísimo pensar en diseñar productos, optimizar, hacer research de usuarios y probar cosas, pero cuando te sientas con un ejecutivo, todo gira en torno a las personas.
context: Lenny asks Ken about the most common blind spots he sees in product leaders. Ken identifies that senior product executives often underestimate how much of their role becomes about managing people rather than managing products. While early-career product managers focus on user research, optimization, and product features, senior leaders spend most of their time on persuasion, team dynamics, and organizational challenges.
vocabulary_highlights: come down to, sit down with

speaker: Kenneth Berger
speaker_expertise: Executive Coaching, Company Building, Product Management
text: If you're more in the people pleasing camp, maybe you're used to not asking at all. You're hoping that people are reading your mind. And if you're sort of more in the control freak camp, maybe you're used to ordering people around and saying, "Go do this now."
text_ko: 사람들 기쁘게 하려는 편이라면 아예 묻지 않는 데 익숙할 거예요. 사람들이 내 마음을 읽어주길 바라고 있죠. 반대로 통제하려는 편이라면 사람들에게 지시해서 “이거 지금 해”라고 말하는 게 더 익숙할 거예요.
text_zh: 如果你比较喜欢讨好别人，可能你根本就不习惯开口要求什么。你总是希望别人能猜到你在想什么。要是你偏向控制狂那一类，可能你习惯了指挥别人，张口就是"赶紧去做这个"。
text_es: Si eres más del tipo que siempre quiere quedar bien con todos, probablemente estés acostumbrado a no pedir nada directamente. Andas esperando que la gente te lea la mente. Y si eres más del tipo controlador obsesivo, tal vez estés acostumbrado a darle órdenes a todo el mundo y decirles "Ve y haz esto ahora mismo."
context: Lenny asks Kenneth how people can know if they need to work on asking for what they want. Kenneth explains that there are two common problematic approaches people take when they struggle with this skill. He identifies that people typically fall into one of two camps when it comes to making requests - either they avoid asking entirely and expect others to intuitively understand their needs, or they become overly controlling and demanding in their communication style.
vocabulary_highlights: people pleasing camp, control freak camp, reading your mind, ordering people around

speaker: Kenneth Berger
speaker_expertise: Executive Coaching, Company Building, Product Management
text: Complaints are great inspiration. Every complaint implies a dream. Let me envision a better future. Let me think about what's an effective way to actually move towards that. See what it's like to not be sort of living in fear all the time.
text_ko: 불만은 훌륭한 영감이에요. 모든 불만에는 더 나은 무언가를 바라는 꿈이 담겨 있어요. 제가 더 나은 미래를 상상하게 해줘요. 그리고 그걸 실제로 향해 나아가게 할 효과적인 방법이 무엇인지 생각하게 해줘요. 늘 두려움에 사로잡혀 살지 않는 삶이 어떤지 느껴보게 해줘요.
text_zh: 客户抱怨其实是很好的灵感来源。每一个抱怨背后都藏着一个期待，让我去想象一个更好的未来。让我想想怎么才能真正有效地朝那个方向努力。看看不用总是提心吊胆过日子是什么感觉。
text_es: Las quejas son una inspiración increíble. Cada queja esconde un sueño. Déjame imaginar un futuro mejor. Déjame pensar en cuál sería una manera efectiva de realmente avanzar hacia eso. Ver cómo sería no estar viviendo con miedo todo el tiempo.
context: Lenny asks Kenneth how people can figure out what they want in their lives and careers, especially for those who struggle with knowing their own desires. Kenneth introduces a technique he calls "dream behind the complaint" - the idea that people are often better at complaining than dreaming, but every complaint contains valuable information about what they actually want. He suggests using complaints as starting points to envision better futures and develop effective strategies to achieve them.
vocabulary_highlights: great inspiration, implies a dream, envision a better future, living in fear

speaker: Kenneth Berger
speaker_expertise: Executive Coaching, Company Building, Product Management
text: Often what I try to introduce people to, and I've learned all this stuff the hard way, believe me, is it's fundamentally disrespectful to go into a meeting already deciding that you're right and the other person is wrong because you can't know that for sure. There's always a new perspective, new data that could come in.
text_ko: 제가 사람들에게 자주 전하려고 하는 말인데요, 이건 저도 뼈저리게 배운 거예요. 회의에 들어가서 이미 '내가 옳고 네가 틀렸다'고 단정해 버리는 건 근본적으로 상대에 대한 무례예요. 왜냐하면 그걸 확실히 알 수는 없으니까요. 언제든 새로운 관점이나 추가적인 데이터가 들어올 수 있어요.
text_zh: 我经常跟别人说的，这些都是我吃了不少亏才悟出来的，就是你带着自己肯定对、对方肯定错的想法去开会，这本身就是不尊重人的表现，因为你根本不可能百分百确定嘛。总会有新的角度、新的信息冒出来的。
text_es: Mira, algo que siempre trato de enseñarle a la gente, y créeme que yo aprendí todo esto a golpes, es que es una falta de respeto total llegar a una reunión ya convencido de que tienes la razón y el otro está equivocado, porque la verdad es que no puedes estar seguro de eso. Siempre puede aparecer una perspectiva nueva, datos que no tenías.
context: Lenny asks Kenneth for an example from his own career where he failed to ask for what he wanted effectively. Kenneth reflects on his tendency to be overly attached to being right, particularly in his product management role. He explains how this mindset of entering conversations with predetermined conclusions about being correct is not only ineffective but also disrespectful to others, as it prevents genuine dialogue and learning from new information.
vocabulary_highlights: the hard way, fundamentally disrespectful, can't know that for sure

speaker: Kenneth Berger
speaker_expertise: Executive Coaching, Company Building, Product Management
text: So one of my favorite techniques here is this concept they call dream behind the complaint. Because you're right that we tend to not be that great always at really dreaming and envisioning and saying, "This is my dream of what I want out of life." That can sound really scary for people, but we're very good at complaining.
text_ko: 제가 여기서 좋아하는 기법 중 하나는 '불만 뒤의 꿈 (dream behind the complaint)'이라는 개념이에요. 말하신 대로 우리는 삶에서 진짜로 원하는 걸 마음껏 꿈꾸고 구체적으로 상상해서 '내가 원하는 삶은 이거야'라고 말하는 데 늘 능숙하지는 않아요. 그런 건 사람들한테 꽤 두렵게 느껴질 수 있는데, 대신 불평하는 건 참 잘하죠.
text_zh: 我特别喜欢用的一个方法叫做"投诉背后的梦想"(dream behind the complaint)。因为你说得对，我们往往不太擅长真正地去畅想和描绘，然后说"这就是我想要的人生"。这听起来可能让人觉得挺吓人的，但是抱怨这件事我们可在行了。
text_es: Una de mis técnicas favoritas es este concepto que llaman "el sueño detrás de la queja" (dream behind the complaint). Porque tienes razón en que no siempre somos muy buenos para realmente soñar y visualizar diciendo "Este es mi sueño de lo que quiero en la vida." Eso puede sonar muy intimidante para la gente, pero para quejarnos sí que somos buenísimos.
context: Lenny asks Kenneth for specific techniques to help people identify what they want, particularly those who struggle with articulating their desires or tend to prioritize others' happiness over their own needs. Kenneth introduces his "dream behind the complaint" technique, explaining that while people often find it intimidating to articulate big dreams or visions, they're naturally skilled at identifying problems and frustrations. He suggests using complaints as a practical starting point for discovering underlying desires.
vocabulary_highlights: dream behind the complaint, dreaming and envisioning, sound really scary

speaker: Kenneth Berger
speaker_expertise: Executive Coaching, Company Building, Product Management
text: So I have a more expansive definition of no than most people, I think, because for me it's not a yes unless it's a hell yes. Because you really want enthusiastic consent. Not just, "Maybe, kinda. I'll try. We'll see. But yeah, absolutely, let's do this."
text_ko: 저는 대부분 사람들보다 '아니오'를 좀 더 넓게 보는 편이에요. 제게는 '헬 예스(hell yes)'가 아니면 예로 안 쳐요. 결국엔 진짜 열렬한 동의(enthusiastic consent)가 필요해요. '음… 아마도, 좀, 해볼게, 지켜보자' 같은 애매한 반응으론 충분하지 않아요.
text_zh: 我对"不"的定义可能比大多数人都要宽泛，因为在我看来，如果不是特别想做的事，那就是不做。你真的需要那种发自内心的认同，而不是那种"也许吧，差不多，试试看，再说吧"的态度。你要的是"好，没问题，咱们就这么干！"
text_es: Yo tengo una definición más amplia del "no" que la mayoría de la gente, creo, porque para mí no es un "sí" a menos que sea un "¡sí rotundo!" Porque realmente necesitas que la gente esté súper convencida. No solo un "A ver... tal vez. Lo intentaré. Ya veremos." Sino más bien "¡Sí, absolutamente, vamos a hacerlo!"
context: Lenny asks Kenneth about overcoming the fear of hearing "no" when asking for what you want. Kenneth explains his philosophy around accepting responses, particularly his belief that anything short of enthusiastic agreement should be treated as a "no." He emphasizes the importance of seeking genuine, wholehearted commitment rather than settling for lukewarm or hesitant responses, as these often lead to problems later when people don't fully follow through on their commitments.
vocabulary_highlights: more expansive definition, hell yes, enthusiastic consent

speaker: Kenneth Berger
speaker_expertise: Executive Coaching, Company Building, Product Management
text: Part of really respecting them is respecting that they can make the choices they want and they're grownups enough that they can deal with the consequences of those choices.
text_ko: 진정으로 그들을 존중한다는 건, 그들이 자기 원하는 선택을 할 권리가 있고 그 선택의 결과를 스스로 감당할 수 있는 어른이라는 걸 인정해 주는 것도 포함돼요.
text_zh: 真正尊重他们，就是要相信他们有能力做自己想做的决定，而且他们都是成年人了，完全可以为自己的选择负责。
text_es: Parte de respetarlos de verdad es entender que pueden tomar sus propias decisiones y que son lo suficientemente adultos como para asumir las consecuencias de esas decisiones.
context: Kenneth discusses a common challenge he sees with "nice" founders who struggle to deliver difficult feedback or create consequences when team members aren't meeting expectations. He's explaining how these leaders often avoid creating accountability because they want to be liked and seen as kind. Kenneth argues that truly respecting people means acknowledging their autonomy to make decisions while also maintaining appropriate professional consequences for those choices.
vocabulary_highlights: really respecting them, grownups enough, deal with the consequences

speaker: Kevin Aluwi
text: I am kind of annoyed at how much it's being mentioned these days. It's really popular in VC-consultant-analyst circles because it sounds really great on a strategy deck because all of the things that are really appealing, we'll talk about lower customer acquisition costs, higher attach rates to different products, talk about higher retention across different services, the ease of cross-selling and upselling. All of these things sound great, but in reality, a lot of those benefits don't pan out.
text_ko: 요즘 이 얘기가 너무 자주 나와서 약간 짜증나요. VC·컨설턴트·애널리스트들(VC-consultant-analyst circles) 사이에서 엄청 인기인데, 전략 데크(strategy deck)에 넣으면 정말 근사하게 들리거든요. 매력적으로 들리는 이야기들 — 고객 획득 비용(customer acquisition costs)은 낮아 보이고, 제품별 추가 구매율(attach rates)은 높아 보이고, 다양한 서비스에서의 유지율(retention)도 좋아 보이고, 교차 판매(cross-selling)나 업셀링(upselling)도 쉽다고 말하죠. 다 좋은 말들이지만, 현실에서는 그런 혜택들이 실제로는 많이 안 나오는 경우가 많아요.
text_zh: 最近到处都在提这个概念，我都有点烦了。在VC、咨询师、分析师这些圈子里特别火，因为放在战略汇报(strategy deck)里听起来特别棒——什么客户获取成本(customer acquisition costs)更低啦，不同产品的关联销售率(attach rates)更高啦，各种服务的用户留存(retention)更好啦，交叉销售(cross-selling)和向上销售(upselling)更容易啦。这些听起来都很美好，但实际上呢，很多好处根本就实现不了。
text_es: Me molesta un poco lo mucho que se está hablando de esto últimamente. Está súper de moda en los círculos de capital de riesgo, consultores y analistas porque suena padrísimo en una presentación de estrategia - hablas de menores costos de adquisición de clientes, mayores tasas de adopción de diferentes productos, mejor retención en distintos servicios, lo fácil que es hacer venta cruzada y upselling. Todo eso suena increíble, pero la realidad es que muchos de esos beneficios no se materializan.
context: Lenny asks Kevin about his thoughts on super apps, given that many US companies like Uber and Twitter are trying to become super apps. Kevin explains his mixed views on the super app strategy, arguing that while super apps sound appealing to VCs and analysts because they promise benefits like lower customer acquisition costs and higher retention, these theoretical advantages often don't materialize in practice.
vocabulary_highlights: don't pan out, VC-consultant-analyst circles, attach rates, cross-selling and upselling

speaker: Kevin Aluwi
text: And so I think this kind of illustrates the importance of having these unifying concepts that are easy for customers to think about the multiple different services. It's not as simple as just saying, oh, we have a lot of engagement, we have a lot of eyeballs at a service. And then you have a super app that makes sense for customers.
text_ko: 그래서 이런 점이 고객들이 여러 다른 서비스를 떠올릴 때 이해하기 쉬운 통합 개념(unifying concepts)을 갖는 것의 중요성을 잘 보여준다고 생각해요. 단순히 참여도(engagement)가 높고 서비스에 트래픽(eyeballs)이 많다고 해서 바로 고객에게 와닿는 슈퍼앱(super app)이 되는 건 아니에요.
text_zh: 所以我觉得这个例子很好地说明了一点，就是你得有一些统一的概念，让客户能够很容易地理解你的各种不同服务。这事儿可不像说"哎呀我们用户活跃度很高，流量也很大"，然后就能做出一个让用户觉得有意义的超级应用(super app)那么简单。
text_es: Entonces, creo que esto demuestra lo importante que es tener conceptos unificadores que les faciliten a los clientes entender los distintos servicios. No es tan sencillo como decir "ay, tenemos mucho engagement, tenemos muchos eyeballs en un servicio" y ya tienes una súper app que tenga sentido para los clientes.
context: Lenny is asking Kevin to elaborate on why super apps don't work as well as expected. Kevin is explaining that customers need a mental framework to understand why different services belong together in one app. He uses examples from Gojek where services connected to drivers made sense to customers (ride-hailing, food delivery, package delivery), but other services like mobile top-ups didn't because they lacked this unifying concept.
vocabulary_highlights: unifying concepts, we have a lot of eyeballs

speaker: Kevin Aluwi
text: But I wish I did have to start there because we actually started as a very scrappy company where we were by far the underfunded player and without brand. We probably would've never gotten to escape velocity beyond that scrappy stage, we've maintained our leadership in Indonesia through a lot of the things that we actually did on the brand side to give you a sense of how scrappy we had to be in competition.
text_ko: 사실 그 지점부터 시작했어야 했으면 좋았을 텐데요. 저희는 정말 자금도 부족하고 브랜드도 없는, 완전 허술한 회사로 시작했거든요. 그 허술한 단계에서 벗어나 탈출 속도(escape velocity)를 얻지 못했을 가능성이 컸을 거예요. 지금 인도네시아에서 리더십을 유지하고 있는 건, 경쟁에서 얼마나 허술하게라도 버텨야 했는지를 보여주는 브랜드 측면에서 저희가 실제로 해온 여러 활동들 덕분이에요.
text_zh: 不过我还真希望我们是从那种状态开始的，因为我们当时确实是个特别能折腾的小公司，资金远远不够，也没什么品牌影响力。要不是那种拼劲儿，我们可能永远都突破不了那个小打小闹的阶段。我们能在印尼保持领先地位，很大程度上靠的就是品牌方面下的功夫。你们可以想象一下，在竞争中我们得有多能折腾才行。
text_es: Pero ojalá hubiéramos tenido que empezar desde ahí porque en realidad arrancamos como una empresa súper luchona donde éramos por mucho los que menos financiamiento teníamos y sin marca. Probablemente nunca habríamos logrado salir de esa etapa de andar raspando centavos, hemos mantenido nuestro liderazgo en Indonesia a través de muchas cosas que hicimos del lado de la marca para que te des una idea de lo ingeniosos que tuvimos que ser en la competencia.
context: Lenny asks Kevin about the importance of brand for startups and how to prioritize it. Kevin explains that while he opened by discussing Gojek's massive scale, he actually prefers to emphasize how they started as an extremely underfunded company. He argues that brand was crucial to their survival and growth, allowing them to compete against much better-funded competitors who had raised over 100 times more capital than Gojek in the early days.
vocabulary_highlights: escape velocity, by far the underfunded player

speaker: Kevin Aluwi
text: And so we would have these actual physical locations where there would be lions of drivers essentially taking cash. And we eventually figured this out of like, okay, we'll work with a bank and integrate with an ATM network and all that. But in the early days we just did it ourselves of building essentially a mini at ATM network, which I think even that sounds too fancy of what it was it. Because it was literally a booth with a vault with cash in it.
text_ko: 그래서 기사님들이 줄 서서 현금을 주고받는 실제 물리적 장소들이 있었어요. 결국엔 은행과 협력해서 ATM 네트워크(ATM network)에 연동하자고 해결책을 찾았죠. 근데 초창기에는 저희가 사실상 미니 ATM 네트워크(mini ATM network)를 직접 만든 셈이었어요. 물론 그 표현도 과하게 들릴 정도예요. 실제로는 말 그대로 현금이 들어 있는 금고(vault)가 있는 작은 부스였거든요.
text_zh: 所以我们当时真的设了一些实体网点，每天都有很多司机排着长队来取现金。后来我们想明白了，觉得应该跟银行合作，接入ATM网络什么的。但是刚开始的时候我们就自己搞，基本上就是搭了个迷你ATM网络吧，不过说ATM网络都太高大上了。说白了就是搭个小亭子，里面放个保险柜装现金。
text_es: Y entonces teníamos estas ubicaciones físicas donde había un montón de conductores básicamente recogiendo efectivo. Y al final nos dimos cuenta de que, bueno, vamos a trabajar con un banco e integrarnos con una red de cajeros automáticos y todo eso. Pero en los primeros días lo hicimos nosotros mismos, construyendo básicamente una mini red de cajeros, aunque creo que hasta eso suena demasiado elegante para lo que realmente era. Porque literalmente era una caseta con una bóveda llena de efectivo.
context: Lenny asks Kevin for stories about how scrappy Gojek was in the early days. Kevin explains one of their biggest challenges: paying drivers when digital payments didn't exist in Indonesia. Since drivers needed to convert their digital earnings to physical cash, Gojek created physical cash distribution centers with vaults where drivers could line up to withdraw their money, essentially building their own primitive ATM network before proper banking integration was available.
vocabulary_highlights: lions of drivers, sounds too fancy

speaker: Kevin Aluwi
text: I really don't like the idea of moats. Again, one of the concepts that gets thrown out a lot by strategy type folks of what's the moat of your business or your product? And usually people are looking for an answer like, oh, look at this capability or look at this feature or look at this distribution partner or all of those kind of things. And I don't believe that any moats are durable over time. Eventually with enough time all moats can be crossed.
text_ko: 저는 해자(moat)라는 개념 자체를 정말 별로 안 좋아해요. 다시 말하지만, 전략 쪽에서 자주 꺼내는 질문 중 하나가 “당신 비즈니스나 제품의 해자가 뭐예요?”인데, 보통 사람들은 “이 역량(capability)을 봐라”, “이 기능(feature)을 봐라”, “이 유통 파트너(distribution partner)를 봐라” 같은 답을 찾으려고 해요. 근데 저는 어떤 해자도 시간이 지나면 오래 버티지 못한다고 생각해요. 결국 시간이 충분히 지나면 모든 해자는 극복될 수 있어요.
text_zh: 我真的不太认同护城河这个概念。你知道，那些做战略的人总是爱问"你们业务或产品的护城河是什么？"通常大家会回答说，看我们这个能力啊，或者这个功能啊，或者这个渠道合作伙伴啊，诸如此类的。但我觉得任何护城河(moat)都不可能长久。时间久了，所有的护城河最终都会被跨越的。
text_es: La verdad es que no me gusta nada el concepto de "fosos defensivos" (moats). Es una de esas ideas que siempre sacan los de estrategia cuando preguntan "¿cuál es el foso defensivo de tu negocio o producto?" Y normalmente la gente busca respuestas como "mira esta capacidad" o "fíjate en esta funcionalidad" o "tenemos este socio de distribución" y cosas así. Pero yo no creo que ningún foso defensivo sea duradero. Al final, con suficiente tiempo, todos los fosos se pueden cruzar.
context: Lenny asks Kevin about Gojek's philosophy of doing hard things instead of taking the easy path that most startups prefer. Kevin explains his contrarian view on competitive moats - the business advantages that supposedly protect companies from competition. He argues that traditional moats like special features or distribution partnerships aren't sustainable because competitors can eventually replicate them, but doing genuinely difficult things creates a more durable advantage.
vocabulary_highlights: gets thrown out a lot, all moats can be crossed, strategy type folks

speaker: Kevin Aluwi
text: And so we actually ran a fairly big private security operation for a fairly long time until it became common to have Gojek drivers do all of these things across cities. We actually ran this very operation intensive thing just to make sure that our drivers could be as safe as possible and it showed our commitment to the driver community, it showed our commitment that we cared.
text_ko: 그래서 저희는 사실 꽤 오랜 기간 꽤 큰 규모의 사설 보안 작전(private security operation)을 운영했어요. 도시마다 Gojek 기사분들이 이런 일들을 직접 하게 되는 게 보편화될 때까지요. 기사분들이 최대한 안전하게 일할 수 있도록 하기 위해서였고, 이렇게 운영 집약적인(operation-intensive) 일을 한 것은 기사 커뮤니티에 대한 저희의 헌신을 보여주고, 우리가 진심으로 신경 쓰고 있다는 걸 증명했어요.
text_zh: 所以我们其实搞了一个挺大规模的私人安保业务，而且做了挺长时间，一直到后来Gojek司机在各个城市做这些事情变得很普遍了。我们当时真的是花了很大力气在运营这个事情，就是为了确保我们的司机能尽可能安全，这也向司机群体表明了我们的态度，表明我们是真心关心他们的。
text_es: Y entonces manejamos una operación de seguridad privada bastante grande durante un buen tiempo, hasta que se volvió común que los conductores de Gojek hicieran todas estas cosas en las ciudades. De hecho manejamos esta operación súper intensiva solo para asegurar que nuestros conductores estuvieran lo más seguros posible, y eso demostró nuestro compromiso con la comunidad de conductores, demostró que realmente nos importaban.
context: Lenny is asking Kevin for more examples of Gojek doing hard things. Kevin describes how Gojek drivers faced violent resistance from motorcycle taxi mafia who controlled certain areas through intimidation and physical assault. Instead of treating drivers as independent contractors and leaving them to handle the violence alone, Gojek hired private security companies to protect their drivers and extract them from dangerous situations, demonstrating their commitment to driver safety.
vocabulary_highlights: operation intensive, showed our commitment

speaker: Kevin Aluwi
text: And so a lot of times I felt like I needed to understand, okay, what is this job? What exactly does it entail is, and seeing how bad I am at it allowed me to understand what good looked like. And so I held a lot of those roles just because I wanted to understand every part of the business as best as I could in order to then find somebody who could do it orders of magnitude better than myself.
text_ko: 그래서 저는 많은 경우에 '이 일이 뭔가? 정확히 어떤 일을 포함하나?'를 이해해야겠다고 느꼈어요. 제가 그 일을 얼마나 못하는지를 보니까 잘하는 모습이 어떤 건지도 알 수 있었죠. 그래서 사업의 모든 부분을 가능한 한 잘 이해하려고 그런 역할들을 많이 맡았어요. 그래야 저보다 훨씬 더(orders of magnitude) 잘할 수 있는 사람을 찾아낼 수 있으니까요.
text_zh: 所以很多时候我觉得自己需要搞明白，这个岗位到底是干什么的？具体包括哪些工作内容？通过发现自己做得有多糟，我反而能看出什么叫做得好。所以我会亲自去做很多不同的角色，就是想尽可能地了解业务的方方面面，这样才能找到比我厉害好几倍的人来做这些事。
text_es: Y entonces muchas veces sentí que necesitaba entender, bueno, ¿qué es este trabajo? ¿Qué implica exactamente? Y ver lo mal que se me daba me permitió entender cómo se veía cuando estaba bien hecho. Así que ocupé muchos de esos puestos simplemente porque quería entender cada parte del negocio lo mejor posible para después encontrar a alguien que lo pudiera hacer muchísimo mejor que yo.
context: Lenny asks Kevin about why he personally held so many different roles at Gojek, from CEO to performance marketer to driver. Kevin explains this wasn't just about being scrappy, but about understanding what excellence looks like in each role. Since experienced talent was scarce in Indonesia's early tech ecosystem, he couldn't easily hire proven professionals, so he first learned the roles himself to understand what good performance looked like before finding people who could do those jobs much better.
vocabulary_highlights: what exactly does it entail, orders of magnitude better

speaker: Kevin Weil
speaker_expertise: AI/ML Products, B2B SaaS, Product Strategy
text: Our general mindset is in two months, there's going to be a better model and it's going to blow away whatever the current set of limitations are. And we say this to developers too. If you're building and the product that you're building is kind of right on the edge of the capabilities of the models, keep going because you're doing something right. Give it another couple months and the models are going to be great, and suddenly the product that you have that just barely worked is really going to sing.
text_ko: 우리의 기본 사고방식은 ‘두 달이면 더 나은 모델(model)이 나와서 지금의 제약들을 완전히 뛰어넘을 거다’예요. 개발자(developer)들에게도 그렇게 말해요. 지금 만들고 있는 제품(product)이 모델(model)의 역량(capabilities) 바로 경계에 걸쳐 있다면 계속 밀고 가라고 해요 — 그건 제대로 하고 있다는 신호예요. 두 달만 더 지나면 모델(model)이 훨씬 좋아지고, 지금 간신히 돌아가던 그 제품(product)이 갑자기 진짜 빛을 발할 거예요.
text_zh: 我们的基本想法是这样的，两个月后肯定会有更好的模型出来，直接把现在这些限制都给突破了。我们也跟开发者们这么说，如果你在做的产品刚好卡在模型能力的边缘上，那就继续干下去，说明你的方向是对的。再给两个月时间，模型会变得特别厉害，到时候你那个现在勉强能跑的产品，突然就会表现得特别棒。
text_es: Nuestra mentalidad en general es que en dos meses va a salir un modelo mejor que va a arrasar con todas las limitaciones que tenemos ahora. Y esto mismo les decimos a los desarrolladores. Si están construyendo algo y el producto que están haciendo está justo en el límite de lo que pueden hacer los modelos actuales, sigan adelante porque van por buen camino. Denle un par de meses más y los modelos van a estar buenísimos, y de repente ese producto que tenían que apenas funcionaba va a ser una joya.
context: Lenny asks Kevin about what it's like working at the center of the AI revolution at OpenAI. Kevin explains their philosophy of 'model maximalism' - the idea that instead of building extensive workarounds for current model limitations, they focus on the fact that AI models improve dramatically every few months. He's advising both internal teams and external developers to push the boundaries of what's currently possible, knowing that upcoming model improvements will make products that barely work today perform exceptionally well in the near future.
vocabulary_highlights: right on the edge, blow away, barely worked, really going to sing

speaker: Kevin Weil
speaker_expertise: AI/ML Products, B2B SaaS, Product Strategy
text: Everywhere I've ever worked before this, you kind of know what technology you're building on, but that's not true at all with AI. Every two months, computers can do something they've never been able to do before and you need to completely think differently about what you're doing.
text_ko: 지금까지 일했던 곳들은 보통 어떤 기술을 기반으로 하는지 어느 정도 알 수 있었어요. 그런데 인공지능(AI)은 전혀 그렇지 않아요. 두 달마다 컴퓨터가 이전에는 못하던 일을 해내니까 우리가 하는 일을 완전히 다르게 생각해야 해요.
text_zh: 我之前在别的公司工作的时候，基本上都清楚自己在用什么技术做事，但搞AI完全不是这么回事。每隔两个月，电脑就能做一些以前根本做不到的事情，你得完全换个思路重新考虑自己在干什么。
text_es: En todos los trabajos que he tenido antes de este, más o menos sabías con qué tecnología ibas a trabajar, pero con la IA eso no aplica para nada. Cada dos meses las computadoras pueden hacer algo que jamás habían podido hacer antes, y tienes que replantear completamente tu forma de enfocar lo que estás haciendo.
context: Lenny asks what's most different about working at OpenAI compared to Kevin's previous roles at traditional tech companies like Twitter, Instagram, and Facebook. Kevin explains that unlike conventional software development where the underlying technology stack remains relatively stable, AI development is fundamentally different because the core capabilities of the models evolve rapidly. This constant advancement in AI capabilities requires product teams to continuously rethink their approach and strategies.

speaker: Kevin Weil
speaker_expertise: AI/ML Products, B2B SaaS, Product Strategy
text: If you're building and the product that you're building is right on the edge of the capabilities of the models, keep going, because you're doing something right because you give it another couple months and the models are going to be great, and suddenly the product that you have that just barely worked is really going to sing.
text_ko: 만약 지금 만들고 있는 제품이 모델(models)의 성능 한계 바로 경계에 있다면, 계속 밀어붙이세요. 그건 잘하고 있다는 신호예요. 몇 달만 더 기다리면 모델들이 훨씬 좋아질 거고, 지금은 간신히 작동하던 제품도 갑자기 정말 빛을 발할 거예요.
text_zh: 如果你在做产品开发，而你的产品刚好卡在模型能力的边缘上，别停下来，继续干，因为你走对路了。再给几个月时间，模型会变得特别厉害，到时候你那个刚刚能跑起来的产品就真的要起飞了。
text_es: Si estás desarrollando algo y tu producto está justo en el límite de lo que pueden hacer los modelos actuales, sigue adelante, porque vas por buen camino. Dale un par de meses más y los modelos van a estar increíbles, y de repente ese producto tuyo que apenas funcionaba va a brillar de verdad.
context: Lenny asks about OpenAI's product philosophy and how they approach building products when the underlying AI technology is constantly improving. Kevin is explaining their 'model maximalism' approach - rather than building extensive workarounds for current AI limitations, they advise developers to build products that push current model capabilities to their limits. His point is that products struggling with today's models will excel as the models rapidly improve over the coming months.
vocabulary_highlights: right on the edge, barely worked, really going to sing

speaker: Kevin Weil
speaker_expertise: AI/ML Products, B2B SaaS, Product Strategy
text: I think you're definitely going to live in a world where you have researchers built into every product team. And I don't even mean just at foundation model companies because I think the future... Actually, frankly one thing that I'm sort of surprised about about our industry in general is that there's not a greater use of fine-tuned models.
text_ko: 저는 분명 앞으로 모든 제품팀에 연구자들이 들어와 있는 세상에서 살게 될 거라고 생각해요. 이게 파운데이션 모델(foundation model) 회사들에만 해당되는 얘기가 아니에요. 솔직히 말하면 업계 전반을 보면서 파인튜닝된 모델들(fine-tuned models)을 훨씬 더 많이 쓰고 있을 줄 알았는데, 그렇지 않은 점이 좀 놀라워요.
text_zh: 我觉得以后肯定会是这样，每个产品团队里都会配研究人员。而且我说的不只是那些做基础模型(foundation model)的公司，因为我觉得未来...说实话，咱们这个行业有一点让我挺意外的，就是微调模型(fine-tuned models)用得还是不够多。
text_es: Creo que definitivamente vas a vivir en un mundo donde tengas investigadores integrados en cada equipo de producto. Y no me refiero solo a las empresas de modelos base porque pienso que el futuro... La verdad, una cosa que me sorprende bastante de nuestra industria en general es que no se use más el fine-tuning de modelos.
context: Lenny asks Kevin about how product teams might change in the future as AI becomes more prevalent. Kevin predicts that product teams across all companies, not just AI companies, will need to include researchers or machine learning engineers. He explains that the future will involve extensive use of fine-tuned models - AI models customized for specific use cases rather than using generic models. This will require teams to have the expertise to adapt and optimize models for their particular product needs.
vocabulary_highlights: built into, foundation model companies, fine-tuned models
topics: Product Management, Learning & Growth, Strategy & Planning

speaker: Kevin Weil
speaker_expertise: AI/ML Products, B2B SaaS, Product Strategy
text: I think if you teach your kids to be curious, to be independent, to be self-confident, you teach them how to think, I don't know what the future holds, but I think that those are going to be skills that are going to be important in any configuration of the future.
text_ko: 제 생각에는 아이들에게 호기심을 갖게 하고, 자립심과 자신감을 길러주면 생각하는 법을 가르치는 거예요. 미래가 어떻게 될지는 모르겠지만, 그런 역량(skills)은 미래가 어떤 모습이든 중요해질 거예요.
text_zh: 我觉得啊，如果你教孩子保持好奇心，培养他们独立自主，让他们有自信，最重要的是教会他们怎么思考，虽然说未来会怎样谁也说不准，但我相信这些能力在任何情况下都会很重要的。
text_es: Yo creo que si les enseñas a tus hijos a ser curiosos, a ser independientes, a tener confianza en sí mismos, si les enseñas a pensar por cuenta propia, no sé qué nos depare el futuro, pero estoy seguro de que esas van a ser habilidades clave en cualquier escenario que se presente.
context: Lenny asks Kevin, who has three children, what skills he's encouraging his kids to learn to prepare for an AI-dominated future. A community member jokingly worried that by 2036, kids might need to compete for spots in roofing or plumbing programs as AI takes over other jobs. Kevin responds with a thoughtful perspective that instead of trying to predict specific career paths, parents should focus on developing fundamental human capabilities that will remain valuable regardless of how technology evolves.
vocabulary_highlights: configuration of the future

speaker: Kevin Weil
speaker_expertise: AI/ML Products, B2B SaaS, Product Strategy
text: It fundamentally disappoints me that this doesn't exist in the world today because the world would be a better place if we'd been able to ship that product. We tried to launch a new blockchain. It was a basket of currencies originally. It was integration into WhatsApp and Messenger. I would be able to send you 50 cents in WhatsApp for free. It should exist.
text_ko: 이런 게 세상에 없다는 게 정말 아쉽고, 만약 이 제품이 출시됐다면 세상이 더 나아졌을 거라고 생각해요. 저희는 새로운 블록체인(blockchain)을 출시하려고 했었어요. 처음에는 여러 통화의 집합체였고, WhatsApp과 Messenger에 통합하는 방식이었죠. 그래서 제가 당신에게 WhatsApp으로 50센트를 무료로 보낼 수 있었을 거예요. 이건 꼭 존재해야 해요.
text_zh: 说实话，这个产品到现在都没能做出来，我真的挺失望的，因为如果我们当时能把这个产品推出来，世界肯定会变得更好。我们试过推出一个新的区块链(blockchain)，最初是一篮子货币的概念，要整合到WhatsApp和Messenger里面。这样我就能在WhatsApp里免费给你转个50美分什么的。这个功能真的应该存在的。
text_es: Me decepciona profundamente que esto no exista hoy en día porque el mundo sería un lugar mejor si hubiéramos logrado sacar ese producto al mercado. Tratamos de lanzar una nueva blockchain. Originalmente era una canasta de monedas. Era integración con WhatsApp y Messenger. Yo te podría enviar 50 centavos por WhatsApp gratis. Esto debería existir.
context: Lenny asks Kevin about Libra, the cryptocurrency project he worked on at Facebook that ultimately failed. Kevin explains that Libra was designed to solve real problems like expensive international remittances, where people pay 20% fees to send money to family in other countries. The project aimed to enable instant, free money transfers through WhatsApp and Messenger using a new blockchain and basket of currencies. Kevin expresses genuine disappointment that this product never launched because he believes it would have made the world better by solving these costly, inefficient payment problems.
vocabulary_highlights: fundamentally disappoints, ship that product, basket of currencies

speaker: Kevin Yien
text: The PM job can become a little too internal, influencing my stakeholders and getting alignment and all these things. But if you can't sell or support your own product, I don't trust you to build the product.
text_ko: 프로덕트 매니저(PM) 일은 이해관계자(stakeholders)를 설득하고 얼라인먼트(alignment)을 맞추는 등 너무 내부적인 일에만 빠질 수 있어요. 그런데 자기 제품을 직접 팔거나 지원(support)을 할 줄 모르면 그 사람을 제품을 만드는 사람으로는 믿을 수 없어요.
text_zh: 产品经理这个工作有时候太偏内部了，就是影响各方利益相关者(stakeholders)啊，搞定大家的一致性(alignment)啊，这些事情。但是如果你连自己的产品都卖不出去或者支持不了，我真的不相信你能把产品做好。
text_es: El trabajo de PM puede volverse demasiado interno, influyendo en los stakeholders y buscando alineación y todas esas cosas. Pero si no puedes vender o dar soporte a tu propio producto, no confío en que puedas construir el producto.
context: Lenny is discussing the importance of writing skills for product managers. Kevin explains that while internal alignment is important, PMs must also be able to create compelling external messaging. He believes that if a PM cannot effectively sell or support their own product to customers, they shouldn't be trusted to build that product in the first place.
vocabulary_highlights: a little too internal, getting alignment, I don't trust you to

speaker: Kevin Yien
text: We all talk about product sense. To me, it's just a fancy way of saying you can make good decisions with insufficient data. PMs need as many reps as possible in making decisions, documenting the rationale behind those decisions, and then crucially seeing the outcome of them.
text_ko: 모두들 프로덕트 센스(product sense)에 대해 얘기하죠. 제겐 그게 불충분한 데이터로도 좋은 결정을 내릴 수 있다는 말을 멋있게 포장한 표현일 뿐이에요. PM들(PMs)은 결정을 내리는 연습을 가능한 한 많이 하고, 그 결정의 근거를 문서로 남기며, 무엇보다 그 결정이 실제로 어떤 결과를 냈는지를 직접 확인해 봐야 해요.
text_zh: 大家都在谈产品感觉(product sense)，在我看来，这不过是个花哨的说法，说白了就是你能在信息不够的情况下做出正确决策。产品经理需要尽可能多地练习做决策，把决策的理由记录下来，然后最关键的是要看到这些决策的结果。
text_es: Todos hablamos del sentido de producto (product sense). Para mí, es solo una forma elegante de decir que puedes tomar buenas decisiones cuando no tienes suficiente información. Los PMs necesitan practicar lo más posible tomando decisiones, documentando el por qué detrás de esas decisiones, y luego - y esto es clave - ver qué resultados dan.
context: Lenny asks Kevin whether every PM should keep a decision log. Kevin explains that product sense, which is often viewed as a mystical quality, is actually just the ability to make good decisions without complete information. He advocates for PMs to practice decision-making by documenting their reasoning and tracking outcomes to improve their judgment over time.
vocabulary_highlights: fancy way of saying, insufficient data, as many reps as possible, crucially
topics: Product Management, Decision Making, Learning & Growth

speaker: Kevin Yien
text: When you get to offer stage, I send an email and I say all the terrible things that are probably going to reinforce their fears. If you can tell them that upfront and they can read that whole email and still be equally excited to join you, find yourself a A+ hire.
text_ko: 오퍼 단계(offer stage)에 이르면, 저는 이메일로 아마도 그들의 걱정을 더 부추길 만한 안 좋은 점들을 전부 솔직하게 적어요. 그런 걸 처음부터 얘기해주고 그 이메일을 끝까지 읽고도 여전히 똑같이 기쁘게 합류하려 한다면, 그런 사람은 A+ 인재(A+ hire)를 찾은 거예요.
text_zh: 到了发offer这个阶段，我会发封邮件，把所有可能让他们更担心的坏消息都说一遍。如果你能提前把这些都告诉他们，他们看完整封邮件后还是一样兴奋地想加入你们，那恭喜你找到了一个A+级别的人才。
text_es: Cuando llegamos a la etapa de oferta, mando un email donde les digo todas las cosas terribles que probablemente van a confirmar sus miedos. Si puedes decirles eso de frente y pueden leer todo el email y aún así siguen igual de emocionados por unirse a ti, ahí tienes una contratación de primera.
context: Lenny introduces Kevin's unique hiring approach called the 'unsell email.' Kevin describes how he sends candidates an honest email at the offer stage outlining all the potential downsides and challenges of the role. His philosophy is that if someone remains equally enthusiastic after learning about these negatives upfront, they're likely to be an excellent long-term hire who won't be surprised or disappointed later.
vocabulary_highlights: reinforce their fears, upfront, find yourself a A+ hire

speaker: Kevin Yien
text: We are not even beneath the dust on the surface when it comes to what's going to change.
text_ko: 앞으로 어떤 변화가 올지는 아직 본질에조차 닿지 못했어요.
text_zh: 说到未来的变化，我们现在掌握的那点东西连皮毛都算不上。
text_es: Ni siquiera hemos arañado la superficie de todo lo que va a cambiar.
context: Lenny asks Kevin about interesting uses of AI in his work. Kevin shares a story about his 7-year-old daughter using Midjourney and asking 'Did I draw that?' after generating an image. He realizes that for her generation, AI image generation is just another tool like a crayon. Kevin uses this powerful metaphor to express how little we understand about the transformative potential of AI technology.
vocabulary_highlights: beneath the dust on the surface

speaker: Kevin Yien
text: When you are building a product, you have this team, engineers, designers, so much potential. The purpose of product management, not the person, but the practice, is to convert that potential into as much realized value for someone as possible, right? Minimum loss.
text_ko: 제품을 만들 때 팀, 엔지니어, 디자이너 등 잠재력이 정말 많아요. 여기서 말하는 제품 관리(product management)는 사람을 가리키는 게 아니라 그 실천을 뜻하는 건데요, 목적은 그 잠재력을 가능한 한 많이 누군가에게 돌아가는 실현된 가치로 전환하는 거예요. 손실은 최소화하면서요.
text_zh: 当你在做产品的时候，你有这个团队，工程师、设计师，潜力巨大。产品管理(product management)这个实践的目的，不是说某个人，而是这套做法，就是要把这些潜力最大化地转换成对用户的实际价值，对吧？损失要最小。
text_es: Cuando estás desarrollando un producto, tienes este equipo, ingenieros, diseñadores, un potencial increíble. El objetivo de la gestión de producto, no me refiero a la persona sino a la práctica en sí, es convertir todo ese potencial en el máximo valor real posible para alguien, ¿verdad? Con la mínima pérdida.
context: Lenny asks Kevin why he discourages people from going straight into product management roles. Kevin uses a physics analogy of potential and kinetic energy to explain his philosophy. He defines product management as the practice of converting a team's potential energy (the collective capabilities of engineers, designers, etc.) into kinetic energy (actual value delivered to customers) with minimal waste or loss.
vocabulary_highlights: so much potential, realized value, minimum loss

speaker: Kevin Yien
text: I think some of this is changing with the advent of large language models and the ability to actually just mimic someone else's tone. But I take inspiration from the camp of Anthony Bourdain, and he has, I'm going to butcher the exact quote but it's something like, 'If you want to know how to make good food, you have to eat a lot of food, and you have to be willing to have a bad meal every now and again.'
text_ko: 이런 부분은 대형 언어 모델(large language models)의 등장과 남의 말투를 실제로 그대로 흉내 낼 수 있는 능력 때문에 좀 달라지고 있는 것 같아요. 저는 앤서니 부르댕의 관점에서 영감을 받아요. 제가 정확한 말을 그대로 옮기진 못하겠지만, 요지는 “좋은 음식을 만드는 법을 알려면 음식을 많이 먹어봐야 하고, 가끔은 맛없는 식사도 감수할 줄 알아야 한다”였어요.
text_zh: 我觉得随着大语言模型(large language models)的出现，这种情况正在发生变化，现在确实可以直接模仿别人的语调了。但我还是很认同安东尼·波登那一派的观点，他有句话我可能说得不够准确，大概意思是："想要做出好吃的菜，你就得多吃，而且要做好偶尔踩雷的准备。"
text_es: Creo que esto está cambiando un poco con la llegada de los modelos de lenguaje grandes y la capacidad de imitar el tono de otra persona. Pero me inspiro en la filosofía de Anthony Bourdain, y él tiene una frase - no la voy a citar exactamente pero es algo así como: "Si quieres saber cocinar bien, tienes que comer mucho, y tienes que estar dispuesto a comerte una mala comida de vez en cuando."
context: Lenny asks Kevin how to become a great writer, since Kevin believes writing skills are crucial for PMs. Kevin acknowledges that AI tools are changing the landscape but still emphasizes the importance of consuming quality content. He quotes celebrity chef Anthony Bourdain's philosophy about food - that to create good work, you must consume a lot of work, including some that isn't great, to develop your taste and judgment.
vocabulary_highlights: with the advent of, I take inspiration from, I'm going to butcher the exact quote, every now and again

speaker: Kevin Yien
text: I explicitly do not mean read a bunch of other PM artifacts. You're not going to become a better writer by reading PRDs or whatever it is or support articles. It needs to be writing that compels. That's the theme I would go back to because that's what you're trying to do at the end of the day.
text_ko: 다른 PM 산출물(PM artifacts)을 잔뜩 읽어보라는 뜻은 분명히 아니에요. PRD들(PRDs)이나 그런 지원 문서(support articles)를 읽는다고 글쓰기 실력이 좋아지진 않아요. 사람을 사로잡는 글, 즉 읽는 이를 설득하고 행동하게 만드는 글이어야 해요. 그게 제가 계속 강조하는 핵심이에요. 결국 그게 당신이 궁극적으로 하려는 일이니까요.
text_zh: 我明确说的不是让你去读一堆产品经理的文档资料。你不可能通过读PRD（产品需求文档）或者支持文章什么的就变成更好的写手。你需要读的是那些真正打动人的文字。这就是我想强调的核心点，因为归根到底，这就是你要做的事情。
text_es: No me refiero para nada a leer un montón de documentos de gestión de producto. No vas a mejorar como escritor leyendo PRDs o lo que sea, o artículos de soporte. Tiene que ser escritura que enganche, que atrape. A eso es a lo que volvería siempre porque al fin y al cabo, eso es lo que estás tratando de lograr.
context: Lenny continues asking about Kevin's advice for becoming a better writer. Kevin clarifies that PMs shouldn't just read typical product management documents like PRDs (Product Requirements Documents) or support articles. Instead, they need to read writing that compels action - writing that moves people to do something different. This is because the ultimate goal of PM writing is to motivate and guide others toward specific actions.
vocabulary_highlights: PM artifacts, writing that compels, at the end of the day

speaker: Kim Scott
text: The question that I like to ask is, 'What could I do or stop doing that would make it easier to work with me?' But do not write down my question because if you sound like Kim Scott and not like yourself, then other people are not going to believe you want the answer. It needs to sound authentic to you.
text_ko: 제가 자주 하는 질문은 "제가 뭘 더 하거나 멈추면 같이 일하기 더 쉬워질까요?"예요. 그런데 그 문장을 그대로 적어 두지는 마세요. 김 스콧처럼 말하면 당신답지 않게 들려서 사람들이 진심으로 답을 해주지 않을 거예요. 당신만의 말투로 진짜 자연스럽게 물어야 해요.
text_zh: 我喜欢问的一个问题是："我可以做什么，或者停止做什么，来让大家跟我合作起来更轻松？"不过别照搬我这个问题，因为如果你说话像金·斯科特(Kim Scott)而不像你自己，别人就不会相信你真的想听到答案。这话得从你嘴里说出来才有说服力。
text_es: La pregunta que me gusta hacer es: '¿Qué podría hacer o dejar de hacer para que sea más fácil trabajar conmigo?' Pero no te copies mi pregunta tal cual, porque si suenas como Kim Scott y no como tú mismo, la gente no va a creer que de verdad quieres saber la respuesta. Tiene que sonar auténtico, que suene a ti.
context: Lenny asks Kim about how to solicit feedback effectively from colleagues and employees. Kim explains that asking generic questions like 'Do you have any feedback for me?' is ineffective because people will just say everything is fine. She shares her go-to question but emphasizes that leaders must adapt the language to sound authentic to their own communication style, otherwise people won't believe they genuinely want honest feedback.
vocabulary_highlights: go-to question, sound authentic, write down my question
topics: Leadership & Management, Communication Skills, Coaching & Development

speaker: Kim Scott
text: If I march into a room and I say, 'Lenny, I'm going to tell you the truth.' I'm kind of implying I've got a pipeline to God and you don't know anything. And that's not what this is all about. This is a dialogue, not a monologue.
text_ko: 제가 방에 들어가서 '레니, 내가 진실을 말해줄게'라고 하면, 마치 제가 신과 직통으로 연결돼 있고 레니는 아무것도 모르는 사람인 것처럼 비춰져요. 그런데 그게 이 일의 취지가 아니에요. 이건 독백이 아니라 대화예요.
text_zh: 如果我走进房间就说，"小李，我来告诉你真相。"这样说话其实就是在暗示我掌握了绝对真理，而你什么都不懂。但事情不是这样的。我们要的是对话，不是一个人在那儿独白。
text_es: Si llego a una sala y le digo a Lenny, "Te voy a decir la verdad", como que estoy dando a entender que tengo línea directa con Dios y que tú no sabes nada. Y no se trata de eso. Esto es un diálogo, no un monólogo.
context: Lenny asks Kim for specific language and phrases to use when giving direct feedback without making people defensive. Kim explains why she uses the term 'candor' instead of 'truth' when giving feedback. She emphasizes that effective feedback should be humble and conversational rather than authoritative, because claiming to know 'the truth' creates an adversarial dynamic instead of collaborative dialogue.
vocabulary_highlights: pipeline to God, march into a room, dialogue, not a monologue

speaker: Kim Scott
text: Six seconds is a really long time. Almost nobody can endure six full seconds of silence. So they'll probably tell you something. So now you've dragged this poor soul out on a conversational limb that they never wanted to go on.
text_ko: 여섯 초는 정말 긴 시간이에요. 거의 아무도 여섯 초 동안의 완전한 침묵을 견디지 못해요. 그래서 대부분 뭔가 말하게 돼요. 그렇게 하면 결국 상대를 원치 않았던 대화의 난처한 상황으로 끌어낸 셈이에요.
text_zh: 六秒钟其实挺长的。基本上没人能忍受整整六秒的沉默。所以他们多半会说点什么。这样一来，你就把这个可怜的家伙逼到了一个他们根本不想聊的话题上。
text_es: Seis segundos es muchísimo tiempo. Casi nadie aguanta seis segundos completos de silencio. Así que probablemente te van a decir algo. Y ahí ya tienes a esta pobre persona metida en una conversación que nunca quiso tener.
context: Kim is explaining her framework for soliciting feedback from colleagues and employees. After asking for feedback, she recommends counting to six seconds of silence to embrace the discomfort, because most people cannot tolerate that much silence and will eventually share something. She describes this as putting the other person in an uncomfortable but necessary position to get honest feedback.
vocabulary_highlights: dragged this poor soul, out on a conversational limb, endure six full seconds
topics: Communication Skills, Leadership & Management, Coaching & Development

speaker: Kim Scott
text: A person takes a huge risk, especially if this person is your employee. A person takes a huge risk to give you critical feedback. And if you do not reward that risk richly, you're never going to get any feedback again.
text_ko: 누군가, 특히 직원이 당신에게 중요한 피드백(critical feedback)을 주려면 큰 위험을 감수하는 거예요. 그 위험을 충분히 보상해주지 않으면 다시는 피드백을 받을 수 없을 거예요.
text_zh: 员工给你提尖锐意见，这其实是冒了很大风险的。如果你不好好回应这种勇气，以后就别想再听到什么真话了。
text_es: Cuando una persona se arriesga enormemente, sobre todo si es tu empleado, para darte feedback crítico o retroalimentación dura, y tú no valoras ese riesgo como se merece, puedes estar seguro de que nunca más vas a recibir ese tipo de comentarios honestos.
context: Kim is explaining the final step in her framework for soliciting feedback - the importance of rewarding candor. She emphasizes that when employees give their boss critical feedback, they're putting themselves in a vulnerable position that could potentially harm their career. Leaders must demonstrate appreciation and take action on the feedback to encourage future honest communication.
vocabulary_highlights: reward that risk richly, takes a huge risk
topics: Leadership & Management, Communication Skills, Coaching & Development

speaker: Kim Scott
text: We all behave like assholes sometimes. And it's a big problem for us as well as for the people around us. And here's my story, when I acted like a jerk, what's yours? And people, that kind of self-awareness, sometimes people talk about inflicted insight like it's some kind of burden, but usually that kind of self-awareness makes people feel lighter.
text_ko: 우리 모두 가끔 정말 못되게 굴 때가 있어요. 그건 우리 자신에게도, 주변 사람들에게도 큰 문제예요. 제 얘기 하나 해볼게요 — 제가 못되게 굴었을 때가 있었어요. 여러분은 어때요? 사람들이 그런 자기 인식을 '강요된 깨달음(inflicted insight)'이라며 부담이라고 할 때도 있는데, 보통은 오히려 그런 자각 때문에 마음이 더 가벼워져요.
text_zh: 我们每个人有时候都会表现得很混蛋，这对我们自己和周围的人来说都是大问题。我来分享一下我当混蛋的经历，你们呢？你知道吗，这种自我认知，有些人觉得深刻的自省(inflicted insight)是种负担，但其实这种自我认知通常会让人感觉轻松很多。
text_es: Todos nos portamos como unos patanes a veces. Y es un gran problema tanto para nosotros como para la gente que nos rodea. Y aquí tienes mi historia, de cuando me comporté como un idiota, ¿cuál es la tuya? Y la gente, ese tipo de autoconocimiento, a veces hablan del insight doloroso como si fuera una carga, pero normalmente ese tipo de autoconocimiento hace que la gente se sienta más liviana.
context: Lenny asks Kim how to help leaders who have low self-awareness and believe obnoxious aggression is the only way to give feedback. Kim explains her approach of first sharing her own stories of when she made mistakes and acted poorly, then asking them for similar examples. This creates a safe space for self-reflection without judgment, helping leaders develop a growth mindset about their behavior.
vocabulary_highlights: inflicted insight, acted like a jerk, makes people feel lighter
topics: Leadership & Management, Coaching & Development, Learning & Growth

speaker: Kim Scott
text: It's not disagreement that poses a risk to our relationships. It's unspoken disagreement. Many, I don't know about you Lenny, but a lot of my best professional relationships began with a good respectful disagreement.
text_ko: 우리 관계를 위협하는 건 의견 차이 자체가 아니에요. 말로 꺼내지 않는, 즉 입밖으로 나오지 않은 의견 차이예요. 레니, 당신은 어떨지 모르겠지만 제 경험으론 가장 좋은 직장 관계들이 존중을 바탕으로 한 건설적인 의견 충돌에서 시작된 경우가 많아요.
text_zh: 对我们关系构成威胁的不是意见分歧，而是那些憋在心里不说出来的分歧。我不知道你怎么样，Lenny，但我很多最好的职场关系都是从一次良性的、相互尊重的争论开始的。
text_es: No es el desacuerdo lo que pone en riesgo nuestras relaciones. Es el desacuerdo que nos callamos. Muchas de mis mejores relaciones profesionales, no sé si te pase igual Lenny, pero muchas empezaron con un buen desacuerdo respetuoso.
context: Kim is explaining how to handle feedback that you disagree with. She advises finding something you can agree with, then respectfully explaining your disagreement rather than just saying thank you and moving on. She makes the point that avoiding conflict by not voicing disagreements actually damages relationships more than having honest, respectful disagreements.
vocabulary_highlights: unspoken disagreement, poses a risk, respectful disagreement
topics: Communication Skills, Leadership & Management, Decision Making

speaker: Kristen Berman
speaker_expertise: Marketing Strategy, User Experience, Product Management
text: We want to remove the field that was like an open text fields where we're asking people an open-ended question and we improved conversion by 40% page over page. So, for sure, some questions are harder and you should not ask them. When questions are easier and it's a drop down multiple choice, this is when you should be trying it.
text_ko: 사람들에게 개방형 질문(open-ended question)을 받아 자유 입력 필드(open text field)처럼 되어 있던 항목을 없애려고 했고, 그 결과 페이지별로 보니 전환율(conversion)이 40%나 올랐어요. 확실히 어떤 질문들은 난이도가 높아서 굳이 물어보면 안 돼요. 질문이 더 쉽고 드롭다운 다지선다(drop-down multiple choice)로 만들 수 있을 때 시도해보는 게 좋아요.
text_zh: 我们把那个开放式文本框给去掉了，就是那种让用户自己填写的开放性问题，结果转化率直接提升了40%。所以肯定有些问题比较难回答，你就别问了。如果问题比较简单，用下拉菜单或者多选的形式，这种时候你就可以试试看。
text_es: Queremos quitar ese campo que era como un texto abierto donde les hacíamos una pregunta muy general, y así mejoramos la conversión en un 40% de página a página. O sea, está claro que hay preguntas que son más complicadas y mejor no hacerlas. Cuando las preguntas son más fáciles y puedes usar un menú desplegable (dropdown) con opciones múltiples, ahí es cuando sí vale la pena intentarlo.
context: Lenny asks about when adding questions to signup flows works versus when it doesn't. Kristen explains that while adding questions can sometimes increase conversion by getting users to think about benefits, the difficulty of the question matters greatly. She shares an example where removing an open text field improved conversion by 40% because open-ended questions require too much cognitive effort from users during signup.
vocabulary_highlights: page over page, drop down multiple choice, cognitive effort

speaker: Kristen Berman
speaker_expertise: Marketing Strategy, User Experience, Product Management
text: We are all present bias, which means we prioritize our present self over our future self, so there are plenty of reasons that somebody, your customer, your user should take an action, but you actually have to give them a reason to take an action today.
text_ko: 우리는 모두 현재 편향(present bias)이 있어서 현재의 나를 미래의 나보다 더 우선시해요. 그래서 누군가, 즉 당신의 고객이나 사용자가 어떤 행동을 해야 할 이유는 많을 수 있지만, 그들이 오늘 당장 행동하도록 만들 만한 이유를 반드시 줘야 해요.
text_zh: 我们都有当下偏见(present bias)的毛病，就是说我们总是优先考虑现在的自己，而不是将来的自己。所以呢，虽然你的客户、用户有很多理由应该采取行动，但你必须得给他们一个今天就行动的理由。
text_es: Todos tenemos sesgo del presente (present bias), o sea que priorizamos nuestro yo actual por encima de nuestro yo futuro, entonces aunque haya muchas razones por las que alguien —tu cliente, tu usuario— debería tomar una acción, en realidad tienes que darle una razón para que actúe hoy mismo.
context: Kristen explains the third component of her 'Three Bs' framework for behavior change - Benefits. She's describing how people naturally prioritize immediate rewards over future benefits, which is a key insight for product design. This means product teams need to provide immediate, tangible benefits to motivate users to take action now, rather than relying solely on long-term value propositions.
vocabulary_highlights: present bias, prioritize our present self, take an action today

speaker: Kristen Berman
speaker_expertise: Marketing Strategy, User Experience, Product Management
text: I like to say we are what we measure, and it really matters what you measure. I'll give you a personal example. LendingClub, a while ago, hired me to increase their conversion flow for borrowers. They're a lending app and they wanted to get more borrowers in the flow. The novel thing here was that they would pay me a lot of money if I hit a bump. It was like a five-point bump and zero if I didn't hit anything.
text_ko: 제가 늘 하는 말이 있어요. 우리는 우리가 측정하는 것이고, 무엇을 측정하느냐가 정말 중요해요. 개인적인 예를 들면요. 얼마 전 LendingClub이 저를 고용해서 대출자 대상 전환 흐름(conversion flow)을 높여달라고 했어요. 그들은 대출 앱(lending app)이고 전환 흐름으로 더 많은 대출자를 유입시키고 싶어했죠. 특이한 점은 제가 어떤 증가(bump)를 만들어내면 거액을 지급하겠다고 한 거예요. 대략 5포인트(5-point) 정도 올리면 큰 보상을 주고, 아무 효과가 없으면 전혀 없다고 했어요.
text_zh: 我经常说，我们就是我们所衡量的东西，你衡量什么真的很重要。我给你举个我自己的例子。之前LendingClub找我去提升他们借款人的转化流程(conversion flow)。他们是个借贷app，想要更多借款人进入流程。这里有个很特别的地方，如果我能达到指标，他们会给我一大笔钱。就是说如果我能提升五个点，钱就到位了，如果没达到就一分钱都没有。
text_es: Me gusta decir que somos lo que medimos, y de verdad importa mucho qué es lo que mides. Te voy a dar un ejemplo personal. LendingClub me contrató hace un tiempo para mejorar su flujo de conversión (conversion flow) de prestatarios. Es una app de préstamos y querían meter más prestatarios en el embudo (funnel). Lo interesante aquí era que me iban a pagar un dineral si lograba un incremento. Era como un aumento de cinco puntos y cero si no conseguía nada.
context: Lenny asks about the potential dark side of behavioral design and how to avoid manipulating users. Kristen responds by explaining how incentive structures drive behavior, using her own experience as an example. She describes how LendingClub's payment structure - paying her only if she achieved a specific conversion increase - created problematic incentives that could lead to predatory lending practices.
vocabulary_highlights: we are what we measure, hit a bump, novel thing

speaker: Kristen Berman
speaker_expertise: Marketing Strategy, User Experience, Product Management
text: So, we did this literature review. We came up with a hypothesis, and we had probably 30 different ways to implement this because the hypothesis is just a starting point. And then, we put it into quantitative research. So, we actually put five different version of the popup in front of over a thousand users, which... We got users from Prolific, which is a platform where you can easily test things.
text_ko: 그래서 문헌 조사(literature review)를 했어요. 가설(hypothesis)을 세웠고, 가설은 출발점일 뿐이라서 이걸 구현할 방법이 아마 30가지 정도 나왔어요. 그다음엔 정량 연구(quantitative research)로 검증했어요. 실제로 팝업(popup) 다섯 가지 버전을 천 명이 넘는 사용자(users)에게 보여줬고, 그 사용자들은 쉽게 테스트할 수 있는 플랫폼인 프로필릭(Prolific)에서 모집했어요.
text_zh: 所以我们做了文献调研，提出了一个假设，然后发现大概有30种不同的实现方式，因为假设只是个起点嘛。接着我们就做定量研究，把5个不同版本的弹窗放到一千多个用户面前测试。这些用户是从Prolific平台找来的，那个平台测东西特别方便。
text_es: Entonces, hicimos esta revisión bibliográfica. Llegamos a una hipótesis, y teníamos como 30 formas diferentes de implementar esto porque la hipótesis es solo un punto de partida. Y luego, lo metimos en investigación cuantitativa. Así que pusimos cinco versiones distintas del popup frente a más de mil usuarios, lo cual... Conseguimos usuarios de Prolific, que es una plataforma donde puedes probar cosas fácilmente.
context: Lenny asks about Kristen's process for developing the TikTok misinformation intervention that reduced shares by 24%. Kristen explains her team's rigorous approach, which starts with academic research, generates multiple implementation ideas, and then tests them quantitatively before building in-product. This systematic approach helps de-risk product launches and increase the likelihood of success.
vocabulary_highlights: literature review, starting point, de-risk

speaker: Kristen Berman
speaker_expertise: Marketing Strategy, User Experience, Product Management
text: We never do a UX study where we're just showing people one thing because they could really like it or hate it, but they could really like or hate all the designs. We have no idea. So, when we're doing this, we always present multiple options, and then relatively look for which one is going to drive the behavior we're intending to change.
text_ko: 우리는 사람들에게 한 가지만 보여주는 UX 조사(UX study)는 절대 안 해요. 그 한 가지를 되게 좋아할 수도, 완전 싫어할 수도 있는데 다른 디자인들도 마찬가지라서 어떤 결과가 나올지 전혀 모르거든요. 그래서 조사할 땐 항상 여러 옵션을 제시하고, 그중에서 우리가 바꾸려는 행동을 실제로 더 잘 이끌어낼 게 뭔지 비교해봐요.
text_zh: 我们做用户体验(UX)研究的时候，从来不会只给用户看一个方案，因为他们可能特别喜欢或者特别讨厌这个方案，但问题是，也许所有的设计他们都会有同样的反应，我们根本不知道啊。所以我们做测试的时候，总是会拿出好几个选项来，然后对比看看哪个更能引导用户做出我们想要的行为改变。
text_es: Nunca hacemos un estudio de UX donde solo les mostramos una cosa a las personas, porque puede que les encante o la odien, pero en realidad podrían amar u odiar todos los diseños por igual. No tenemos ni idea. Entonces, cuando hacemos esto, siempre presentamos varias opciones, y luego comparamos relativamente para ver cuál va a impulsar el comportamiento que queremos cambiar.
context: Lenny asks for advice on how product teams can conduct their own behavioral research. Kristen emphasizes the importance of comparative testing rather than absolute feedback. She explains that showing users only one design option provides no useful data since users might like or dislike all potential designs equally - the key insight comes from relative comparison between multiple options.
vocabulary_highlights: relatively look for, intending to change, comparative testing

speaker: Kristen Berman
speaker_expertise: Marketing Strategy, User Experience, Product Management
text: There's kind of two steps. One, you can outline the full high level flow where you're saying maybe there's 50 steps in getting to the behavior, and you can do this before they hit your product, too. But when we're working with just a very kind of... We want to help a team grow their product versus develop a new product, if it's just about growing and improving the current product, we'll do a deck of 200, 300 slides of screenshots where it's just very detailed analysis of the steps that it takes to get to the behavior change.
text_ko: 사실 두 단계가 있어요. 먼저 전체 하이레벨 플로우(high-level flow)를 개괄하는 건데, 어떤 행동(behavior change)에 도달하기까지 50단계쯤 있다고 보고 흐름을 쭉 정리해요. 이건 사용자가 제품에 접속하기 전에도 할 수 있어요. 그런데 우리가 새 제품을 만드는 게 아니라 팀이 현재 제품을 성장시키고 개선하도록 도와주는 상황이라면 훨씬 더 자세히 들어가요. 현재 제품을 성장시키는 게 목적이라면 행동 변화(behavior change)에 이르는 단계들을 아주 세밀하게 분석한 스크린샷(screenshots) 위주의 200~300슬라이드짜리 덱(deck)을 만들어요.
text_zh: 基本上分两步走。第一步，你可以先把整个大框架梳理出来，比如说要达到这个行为改变可能需要50个步骤，而且这个在用户接触你产品之前就可以做。但如果我们现在主要是帮一个团队把现有产品做大做强，而不是从头开发新产品的话，那我们就会做一个200到300页截图的PPT，非常详细地分析每一个步骤，看怎么才能实现行为改变。
text_es: Básicamente son como dos pasos. Uno, puedes mapear todo el flujo general de alto nivel donde dices que tal vez hay 50 pasos para llegar al comportamiento que buscas, y esto lo puedes hacer incluso antes de que lleguen a tu producto. Pero cuando trabajamos con algo más... Digamos que queremos ayudar a un equipo a hacer crecer su producto en lugar de desarrollar uno nuevo, si se trata solo de hacer crecer y mejorar el producto actual, hacemos una presentación de 200, 300 slides con capturas de pantalla donde es un análisis súper detallado de todos los pasos que se necesitan para lograr ese cambio de comportamiento.
context: Lenny asks about the behavioral diagnosis process that Kristen mentioned as a key tool for product teams. A behavioral diagnosis is like a detailed journey map that analyzes every step users take to complete a desired behavior. Kristen explains how her team creates extremely detailed documentation (200-300 slides) of user flows, then overlays psychological insights to identify barriers at each step.
vocabulary_highlights: high level flow, detailed analysis, behavior change

speaker: Krithika Shankarraman
text: Everyone knew of ChatGPT, but when you clicked one zoom level further, the thing that came up was, 'I don't know what to use it for. I don't know what it replaces. Should I be using search for this? Should I be using ChatGPT for this? How can it even help me?' And so the work of marketing ended up becoming creating this sort of use case epiphany where people could say, 'I had no idea ChatGPT can do that. And yeah, maybe I should be using it for X, Y, Z reason in my own life.'
text_ko: 모두가 ChatGPT를 알고는 있었어요. 그런데 한 단계만 더 들어가 보면 사람들이 흔히 하는 말이, "이걸 뭘 위해 써야 하지? 뭘 대체하는 거지? 검색(search)을 써야 하나, ChatGPT를 써야 하나? 이게 어떻게 도움을 주지?" 같은 거였어요. 그래서 마케팅은 결국 사람들이 "어? ChatGPT가 이런 것도 할 수 있구나. 아, 내 생활에서 X, Y, Z 이유로 이걸 써봐야겠다"라고 느끼게 해주는, 일종의 사용 사례의 깨달음(use case epiphany)을 만들어내는 일이 됐어요.
text_zh: 大家都知道ChatGPT这个东西，但你再深入了解一下就会发现，用户其实会说："我也不知道拿它干什么用啊，不知道它能替代什么。这种情况我是该用搜索还是该用ChatGPT？它到底能帮我什么忙？" 所以营销的重点就变成了要给用户创造一种恍然大悟的感觉，让他们说："哇，原来ChatGPT还能这么用！对啊，我在自己生活中确实应该用它来做这些那些事情。"
text_es: Todo el mundo conocía ChatGPT, pero cuando profundizabas un poquito más, lo que salía a la luz era: 'No tengo ni idea de para qué usarlo. No sé qué está reemplazando. ¿Debería usar el buscador para esto? ¿O debería usar ChatGPT? ¿Cómo me puede ayudar siquiera?' Entonces el trabajo de marketing terminó siendo crear como una especie de momento eureka de casos de uso, donde la gente pudiera decir: 'No tenía ni idea de que ChatGPT podía hacer eso. Y sí, tal vez debería estar usándolo por tal, tal y tal razón en mi propia vida.'
context: Lenny asks Krithika about the value that marketing adds to a product like ChatGPT, which seems so magical that it wouldn't need marketing support. Krithika explains that while awareness wasn't the problem for ChatGPT - everyone had heard of it - the real challenge was helping people understand practical applications. The marketing team's role became creating moments of realization where users discovered new ways to incorporate ChatGPT into their daily workflows and decision-making processes.
vocabulary_highlights: clicked one zoom level further, use case epiphany, X, Y, Z reason

speaker: Krithika Shankarraman
text: A lot of marketing metrics tend to be vanity metrics about the number of clicks that you got, number of views, number of impressions. I think those are all bullshit numbers. What is that experience that you want your customers to come away with when they interact with your brand?
text_ko: 많은 마케팅 지표들이 클릭 수, 조회수, 노출 수처럼 보여주기 식의 허영 지표(vanity metrics)인 경우가 많아요. 저는 그런 건 전부 의미 없는 숫자들이라고 생각해요. 브랜드와 상호작용했을 때 고객이 어떤 경험을 얻어가길 원하나요?
text_zh: 很多营销指标其实都是虚荣指标(vanity metrics)，就是点击量啊、浏览量啊、曝光量啊这些。我觉得这些数据都是扯淡。关键是你希望客户和你的品牌接触后能有什么样的体验感受？
text_es: Muchas de las métricas de marketing suelen ser métricas de vanidad (vanity metrics) sobre cuántos clics conseguiste, cuántas visualizaciones, cuántas impresiones. Yo creo que todos esos números son pura patraña. ¿Cuál es esa experiencia que quieres que tus clientes se lleven cuando interactúan con tu marca?
context: During her introduction, Krithika discusses the common problem with marketing measurement and focus. She argues against focusing on surface-level engagement metrics like clicks, views, and impressions, calling them meaningless. Instead, she advocates for measuring the actual customer experience and the lasting impression that interactions with your brand create. This reflects her philosophy that marketing should focus on meaningful outcomes rather than vanity metrics that look good in reports but don't drive real business value.
