vocabulary_highlights: vanity metrics, bullshit numbers, come away with

speaker: Krithika Shankarraman
text: So I was an engineer before I became a marketer, and so I have brought a little bit of an engineer's framework to the marketing side of the house. And so something that I've tried to do is put together a four-step process that has served me pretty well. The first step here is diagnosing. So, diagnosing the actual problem.
text_ko: 저는 마케터가 되기 전에 엔지니어였어요, 그래서 엔지니어식 프레임워크(engineer's framework)를 마케팅 쪽에 조금 적용했어요. 제가 해온 것 중 하나는 제게 꽤 잘 맞았던 4단계 프로세스(four-step process)를 정리하는 거였어요. 여기서 첫 번째 단계는 진단(diagnosing)이에요. 즉 실제 문제를 진단하는 거예요.
text_zh: 我之前是做工程师的，后来才转做市场营销，所以我把一些工程师的思维框架带到了市场这边来。我总结出了一套四步走的方法，用下来效果挺不错的。第一步就是诊断问题，找出真正的问题到底是什么。
text_es: Entonces, yo era ingeniero antes de meterme al marketing, y he traído un poco del enfoque de ingeniero al lado del marketing. Algo que he tratado de hacer es armar un proceso de cuatro pasos que me ha funcionado bastante bien. El primer paso es diagnosticar. O sea, diagnosticar el problema real.
context: Lenny asks Krithika what people should do instead of copying successful marketing playbooks from other companies. Krithika explains her engineering background and how it shaped her systematic approach to marketing. She introduces her four-step framework that starts with diagnosis - systematically identifying the real problem before jumping to solutions. This methodical approach contrasts with the common tendency to immediately implement tactics that worked for other companies without understanding the underlying context and challenges.
vocabulary_highlights: side of the house, served me pretty well, diagnosing the actual problem

speaker: Krithika Shankarraman
text: And then, this is the critical step. The next one is you have to intentionally take a different path than what everyone else is doing. And so driving a strategy that sort of sets the company apart is really critically important. I think it's so core to the discipline of marketing, ensuring that differentiation in the market.
text_ko: 그리고 이게 결정적인 단계예요. 다음으로는 의도적으로 모두가 가는 길과는 다른 길을 택해야 해요. 그래서 회사를 차별화시키는 전략(strategy)을 세우고 추진하는 게 정말 중요해요. 저는 시장에서의 차별화(differentiation)를 확보하는 게 마케팅(marketing)이라는 분야의 핵심이라고 생각해요.
text_zh: 然后呢，这一步特别关键。接下来你必须要有意识地走一条跟别人不一样的路。所以说，制定一个能让公司脱颖而出的策略真的是太重要了。我觉得这就是营销这门学问的核心所在，就是要确保你在市场上有差异化(differentiation)。
text_es: Y entonces, este es el paso clave. Lo que sigue es que tienes que tomar intencionalmente un camino distinto al que están siguiendo todos los demás. Entonces, impulsar una estrategia que realmente diferencie a la empresa es súper importante. Creo que es fundamental en la disciplina del marketing, asegurar esa diferenciación en el mercado.
context: Krithika is explaining the third step of her DATE framework (Diagnose, Analyze, Take a different path, Experiment). After diagnosing the problem and analyzing what competitors are doing, she emphasizes that the crucial step is deliberately choosing a different approach. She argues that differentiation isn't just nice to have - it's fundamental to effective marketing. Rather than trying to execute the same strategies as competitors but slightly better, successful companies must find unique positioning and approaches that set them apart in the marketplace.
vocabulary_highlights: take a different path, sets the company apart, core to the discipline

speaker: Krithika Shankarraman
text: Really, what you want to be looking at is your impact on either signups if you're a self-serve product, PLG, or in terms of a B2B company, sales leads and revenue that you're driving, pipeline and opportunity that you're driving. So we diagnosed that and we found that for the most part, our paid social channels were doing not much for us.
text_ko: 정말로 봐야 할 건, 셀프서비스 제품(self-serve product)이거나 제품 주도 성장(product-led growth, PLG) 모델이라면 가입(signups)에 미치는 영향이고, B2B 기업(B2B company)의 경우라면 우리가 만들어내는 영업 리드(sales leads), 매출(revenue), 파이프라인(pipeline)과 오퍼튜니티(opportunity)에 미치는 영향이에요. 그래서 분석해봤더니 대체로 유료 소셜 채널(paid social channels)은 우리한테 별로 효과가 없더라고요.
text_zh: 其实你真正要关注的是你的影响力，如果你是自助服务产品、PLG（产品导向增长）的话，就看注册量；如果是B2B公司的话，就看你带来的销售线索和收入，还有你推动的销售管道(pipeline)和商机。所以我们诊断了一下，发现我们的付费社交渠道基本上没给我们带来什么效果。
text_es: La verdad es que lo que tienes que mirar es tu impacto, ya sea en registros si tienes un producto de autoservicio, PLG, o si eres una empresa B2B, en los leads de ventas y los ingresos que estás generando, el pipeline y las oportunidades que estás creando. Entonces hicimos ese diagnóstico y descubrimos que en su mayoría, nuestros canales de redes sociales pagadas no nos estaban dando casi nada.
context: Krithika is sharing a case study from Retool where she applied her diagnostic framework. She had just criticized vanity metrics like clicks and impressions, emphasizing that marketers should focus on business outcomes that actually matter. In this example, she explains how they discovered their paid social channels weren't generating meaningful sales leads or revenue despite potentially showing good engagement numbers. This diagnostic step revealed they needed to invest in completely new marketing engines rather than just scaling existing channels.
vocabulary_highlights: self-serve product, PLG, doing not much for us

speaker: Krithika Shankarraman
text: It seems like there's a playbook for everything, there is a framework for everything, but the reality is you have to spend the hours and the time to really understand your customer, and there is no replacement for that, and there isn't going to be even with the advent of AI.
text_ko: 모든 일에 플레이북(playbook)이 있고 프레임워크(framework)가 다 있는 것처럼 보이지만, 실제로는 고객을 진짜로 이해하려면 시간과 노력을 들여 직접 파고들어야 해요. 그걸 대신할 방법은 없고, AI(AI)가 등장해도 마찬가지예요.
text_zh: 现在好像什么都有套路，什么都有框架，但实际上你还是得花时间、下功夫去真正了解你的客户，这个是没法替代的，就算AI再发达也一样。
text_es: Parece que hay una guía paso a paso para todo, un marco de referencia (framework) para todo, pero la realidad es que tienes que dedicar las horas y el tiempo para realmente entender a tu cliente, y eso no se puede reemplazar con nada, y no va a cambiar ni siquiera con la llegada de la inteligencia artificial.
context: This is Krithika's closing advice to listeners, summarizing her main philosophy about marketing. Throughout the conversation, she has consistently argued against following generic playbooks and frameworks, instead advocating for deep, first-hand customer understanding. She emphasizes that despite the availability of countless marketing frameworks and the emergence of AI tools, there is no substitute for investing significant time and effort in truly comprehending your customers' needs, problems, and behaviors. This hands-on approach forms the foundation of effective marketing strategy.
vocabulary_highlights: there is no replacement for that, with the advent of AI

speaker: Kunal Shah
speaker_expertise: Product Management, Growth Strategy, Marketing Strategy
text: I think CRED's insight was actually quite simple. We realized that unfortunately the value of time and per capita income is concentrated with 25 million families and therefore focusing on them is important. And they are a lot more global in their approach versus the rest of India.
text_ko: 사실 CRED의 인사이트는 꽤 단순했어요. 시간의 가치와 1인당 소득(per capita income)이 2,500만 가구에 집중돼 있어서 그들을 공략하는 게 중요하다고 본 거예요. 그리고 그들은 인도 다른 지역 사람들보다 훨씬 더 글로벌한 접근을 해요.
text_zh: 我觉得CRED的洞察其实挺简单的。我们发现一个现实就是，时间价值和人均收入其实就集中在2500万个家庭身上，所以必须得重点关注这部分人群。而且这些人的思维方式比印度其他人群要国际化得多。
text_es: Creo que la perspectiva de CRED era bastante sencilla en realidad. Nos dimos cuenta de que desafortunadamente el valor del tiempo y el ingreso per cápita se concentra en 25 millones de familias, así que enfocarnos en ellas es clave. Y tienen un enfoque mucho más global comparado con el resto de India.
context: Lenny asks Kunal what he's learned during his journey building CRED over the past six years compared to his previous startups. Kunal explains that CRED's core strategy was to focus on India's wealthiest 25 million families rather than trying to serve the entire Indian market. He recognized that this demographic has higher per capita income and values time differently than the broader Indian population, making them more similar to global consumers in their behavior and spending patterns.
vocabulary_highlights: per capita income, concentrated with, global in their approach

speaker: Kunal Shah
speaker_expertise: Product Management, Growth Strategy, Marketing Strategy
text: I often tell people that entrepreneurs are uncertainty absorbers for everybody- for employees, for investors, for customers- and therefore they get rewarded for being those people who remove uncertainty from people's lives. But the kind of expectations keep changing at companies of scale.
text_ko: 저는 종종 사람들에게 기업가(entrepreneurs)는 직원들이나 투자자들, 고객들처럼 모두의 불확실성을 흡수해 주는 존재, 즉 불확실성 흡수자(uncertainty absorbers)라고 말해요. 그래서 사람들 삶의 불확실성을 제거해 주는 사람들이 그에 대한 보상을 받는다고요. 다만 규모가 큰 회사들(companies of scale)에서는 그런 기대치가 계속 바뀌어요.
text_zh: 我经常跟人说，创业者其实就是帮所有人消化不确定性的——帮员工、帮投资人、帮客户消化，所以他们能拿到回报，就是因为他们把别人生活中的不确定性给解决了。但是公司做大了以后，大家对你的期待就一直在变。
text_es: Siempre les digo a las personas que los emprendedores son como esponjas de incertidumbre para todos - para los empleados, para los inversionistas, para los clientes - y por eso se les recompensa por ser esas personas que le quitan la incertidumbre a la vida de la gente. Pero el tipo de expectativas sigue cambiando en las empresas grandes.
context: Kunal is discussing the lessons he's learned while scaling CRED from a startup to a larger company. He's explaining how the founder's role evolves as the company grows, and how different stakeholders (seed investors vs growth investors) have different tolerance levels for uncertainty. This insight comes from his experience managing expectations across different stages of company growth and different types of investors on CRED's cap table.
vocabulary_highlights: uncertainty absorbers, companies of scale

speaker: Kunal Shah
speaker_expertise: Product Management, Growth Strategy, Marketing Strategy
text: One of the things I've learned is that profit pools of a country tell you a lot about what the country values. And trying to copy somebody else's profit pool to your country will not be a wise idea because the country's values are demonstrated in what profit pools exist.
text_ko: 제가 배운 것 중 하나는 한 나라의 수익 풀(profit pools)이 그 나라가 무엇을 중요하게 여기는지를 많이 알려준다는 거예요. 그래서 다른 나라의 수익 풀을 그대로 따라 하려는 건 현명한 생각이 아니에요. 어떤 수익 풀들이 존재하는지가 그 나라의 가치관을 드러내거든요.
text_zh: 我发现一个道理，就是看一个国家哪些行业最赚钱，基本上就能看出这个国家重视什么。你要是想把别人国家的赚钱模式照搬到自己国家来，那肯定是不明智的，因为每个国家的价值观不一样，这直接决定了哪些生意能做得起来。
text_es: Una de las cosas que he aprendido es que los sectores rentables de un país te dicen mucho sobre lo que ese país valora de verdad. Y tratar de copiar los sectores rentables de otro país no va a ser buena idea, porque los valores de cada país se reflejan en qué sectores generan ganancias ahí.
context: Kunal is sharing insights from building CRED about understanding different markets. A 'profit pool' refers to where the most profitable companies and business models exist in an economy. He's explaining that entrepreneurs shouldn't simply copy successful business models from other countries because what's profitable reflects cultural values - for example, India has fewer profitable retail companies compared to Western markets due to different consumption patterns and cultural factors like low divorce rates.
vocabulary_highlights: profit pools, will not be a wise idea

speaker: Kunal Shah
speaker_expertise: Product Management, Growth Strategy, Marketing Strategy
text: So when you're not paid an hourly salary, the concept of time is not the same. And when the concept of time is not the same, paying for time is hard to do. And therefore you'll see a lot of Indians who make, let's say, I don't know, maybe $100 an hour, but still spend an hour to spend $10 on a flight ticket because that's what it is.
text_ko: 그래서 시급으로 받지 않으면 시간에 대한 개념이 달라져요. 시간이 다르면 시간을 돈으로 계산해서 지불하기도 어렵고요. 그래서 예를 들어 어떤 인도인들은 시간당 100달러 정도 버는데도 비행기 표 10달러를 아끼려고 한 시간을 쓰는 걸 보게 돼요. 그런 거예요.
text_zh: 所以当你不是按小时拿工资的时候，你对时间的概念就不一样了。时间概念不一样了，要为时间付费就很难做到。所以你会看到很多印度人，比如说一小时能赚100美金吧，但还是会花一个小时去省10美金的机票钱，就是这么个情况。
text_es: Entonces cuando no te pagan por horas, el concepto del tiempo no es el mismo. Y cuando el concepto del tiempo no es el mismo, es difícil ponerle precio al tiempo. Por eso vas a ver muchos indios que ganan, no sé, digamos unos $100 la hora, pero que igual se pasan una hora buscando para ahorrarse $10 en un boleto de avión porque así es la cosa.
context: Lenny asks about the difference between DAUs (daily active users) and ARPUs (average revenue per user) in India - why it's easy to get users but hard to make money per user. Kunal explains that Indians have never been paid hourly wages, unlike Americans who typically start with hourly jobs. This cultural difference means Indians don't mentally calculate the value of their time in the same way, making them less willing to pay for time-saving services or convenience.
vocabulary_highlights: concept of time, paying for time is hard to do

speaker: Kunal Shah
speaker_expertise: Product Management, Growth Strategy, Marketing Strategy
text: What happens is there is concentration of trust. So you will see that super apps, superstars, super companies all exist in low trust markets because the lack of trust creates concentration of trust, and therefore you will see one app can do 400 things.
text_ko: 결국 일어나는 건 신뢰의 집중(concentration of trust)이에요. 신뢰가 낮은 시장일수록 슈퍼앱(super apps)이나 슈퍼스타(superstars), 슈퍼 기업(super companies)이 등장하죠. 신뢰가 부족하니까 신뢰가 한곳으로 쏠리고, 그 결과 한 앱이 400가지 일을 하게 되는 걸 보게 돼요.
text_zh: 其实就是这样，信任会集中到少数几个地方。所以你会发现，超级应用(super apps)、超级明星、超级公司，这些都出现在信任度比较低的市场里，因为大家普遍不信任，反而会把信任都集中给少数几个，所以你看一个应用能做四百件事情。
text_es: Lo que pasa es que se concentra la confianza. Entonces vas a ver que las súper apps, las empresas estrella, las súper compañías, todas existen en mercados donde hay poca confianza, porque justamente esa falta de confianza hace que la confianza se concentre, y por eso ves que una sola app puede hacer 400 cosas diferentes.
context: Lenny asks why focus is considered a curse in Asian markets, contrary to the common US advice of building one thing well. Kunal explains the concept of 'low trust markets' - developing countries where institutions aren't strong enough to protect consumers from bad business practices. In these markets, consumers concentrate their trust in a few proven brands rather than trying new ones, which is why super apps (like WeChat) and conglomerate companies (like Tata in India) are successful there.
vocabulary_highlights: concentration of trust, low trust markets

speaker: Kunal Shah
speaker_expertise: Product Management, Growth Strategy, Marketing Strategy
text: I think a curious person is somebody who is constantly demonstrating that they are not proud of their expertise, and they will demonstrate extraordinary amounts of excitement when they face a problem which they have no clue how to solve. And therefore a lot of people stop growing because they want to constantly demonstrate their expertise versus demonstrating their curiosity.
text_ko: 저는 호기심 많은 사람은 자신이 전문가라는 걸 내세우지 않는 사람이라고 생각해요. 그리고 어떻게 풀어야 할지 전혀 감이 안 오는 문제를 만나면 엄청 신나하고 흥분해요. 그래서 많은 사람이 더 이상 성장하지 못해요—계속 전문성만 보여주려고 해서 호기심을 드러내지 않기 때문이에요.
text_zh: 我觉得有好奇心的人就是那种从来不会炫耀自己专业能力的人，遇到完全不知道怎么解决的问题时，他们反而会特别兴奋。所以很多人之所以停止成长，就是因为他们总想着展示自己的专业性，而不是保持好奇心。
text_es: Creo que una persona curiosa es alguien que constantemente demuestra que no se cree el experto de todo, y se emociona muchísimo cuando se encuentra con un problema que no tiene ni idea de cómo resolver. Por eso mucha gente deja de crecer, porque siempre quiere demostrar lo que sabe en lugar de demostrar su curiosidad.
context: Lenny asks Kunal why curiosity is so important to him, noting that he has a show called CRED Curious and often talks about the power of curiosity. Kunal explains that curious people aren't focused on showing off what they already know, but instead get excited about problems they can't solve. He contrasts this with people who prioritize demonstrating their existing expertise, which he believes limits their growth and ability to adapt to new challenges.
vocabulary_highlights: not proud of their expertise, extraordinary amounts of excitement, stop growing

speaker: Kunal Shah
speaker_expertise: Product Management, Growth Strategy, Marketing Strategy
text: I recently asked the question: which species or animals have survived for more than 100 million years without changing too much and what is common in all of them? So GPT came up with an interesting answer which says that sharks, horseshoe crabs, crocodiles, and all of these animals have survived to do this thing.
text_ko: 얼마 전에 "어떤 종(species)이나 동물들이 1억 년(100 million years) 넘게 크게 변하지 않고 살아남았고, 그런 종들에겐 공통점이 뭘까?"라고 물어봤어요. 그래서 GPT가 흥미로운 답을 줬는데요, 상어(sharks), 투구게(horseshoe crabs), 악어(crocodiles) 같은 동물들이 바로 그런 식으로 오래 살아남았다고 했어요.
text_zh: 我最近问了一个问题：哪些动物物种能在一亿多年里基本不变地存活下来，它们有什么共同点？GPT给了个挺有意思的答案，说鲨鱼、鲎、鳄鱼这些动物都做到了这一点。
text_es: Hace poco me hice esta pregunta: ¿qué especies o animales han sobrevivido más de 100 millones de años sin cambiar demasiado y qué tienen en común todos ellos? Entonces le pregunté al GPT y me dio una respuesta muy interesante que dice que los tiburones, los cangrejos herradura, los cocodrilos, y todos estos animales han logrado sobrevivir haciendo esto.
context: Kunal is explaining how he uses ChatGPT to explore random questions that satisfy his curiosity. He shares an example where he asked about long-surviving animal species and discovered they share three traits: ability to reduce metabolism at will, high conversion rates when hunting for food, and strong adaptation skills. He draws parallels between these survival traits and successful business principles, showing how curiosity-driven questions can lead to useful insights.
vocabulary_highlights: without changing too much, survived to do this thing

speaker: Lane Shackleton
speaker_expertise: Product Management, Team Building, Product Strategy
text: Moments that stretch you or moments that you feel uncomfortable in or you find yourself saying, "Oh shit. I shouldn't be here," or, "I'm under qualified to be here," those are the moments you should be seeking out. Those are the moments that stretch you and give you a new foundation. So oftentimes you'll hear a career question like, "Hey, do you feel like you're growing in your role?" And that's a very ambiguous, in my opinion, way to ask this question.
text_ko: 자신을 시험에 들게 하거나 불편하게 만드는 순간들, 또는 "어휴, 내가 여기 있어도 되는 걸까?", "내가 여기 올 자격이 없나?"라고 느끼게 되는 순간들이 바로 찾아야 할 순간이에요. 그런 순간들이 당신을 한 단계 끌어올리고 새로운 토대를 마련해줘요. 그래서 흔히들 "지금 맡은 역할에서 성장하고 있다고 느껴요?"라고 묻는데, 제 생각엔 그 질문은 너무 애매해요.
text_zh: 那些让你感到压力的时刻，或者让你不舒服的时刻，或者你会想"我去，我不应该在这儿"，或者"我根本不够格在这儿"的时刻，这些才是你应该主动去寻找的时刻。正是这些时刻能够锻炼你，给你打下新的基础。所以你经常会听到有人问职业相关的问题，比如"嘿，你觉得你在这个岗位上有成长吗？"在我看来，这种问法太模糊了。
text_es: Los momentos que te sacan de tu zona de cómodo o cuando te sientes incómodo, o cuando te dices "Ay, no mames, no debería estar aquí" o "No estoy calificado para esto", esos son exactamente los momentos que deberías buscar. Esos son los momentos que te hacen crecer y te dan una nueva base. Entonces muchas veces escuchas preguntas de carrera como "Oye, ¿sientes que estás creciendo en tu puesto?" Y esa es una manera muy ambigua, en mi opinión, de hacer esa pregunta.
context: Lenny asks Lane about career growth and how to assess whether someone is developing professionally. Lane explains his concept of "oh shit moments" - situations where you feel unqualified or uncomfortable because you're being stretched beyond your current capabilities. He argues that these moments are actually indicators of growth and should be actively sought out, rather than the typical vague question about whether someone feels they're growing in their role.
vocabulary_highlights: stretch you, under qualified, very ambiguous, in my opinion

speaker: Lane Shackleton
speaker_expertise: Product Management, Team Building, Product Strategy
text: The core job of a product person in general is to turn ambiguity into clarity. And if you think about the job of a product leader or a product manager, everything is ambiguous all the time. It's like what's my role on this team? What problem are we solving? Who's the target customer? What prototype is going to solve this particular problem? So it's literally everything.
text_ko: 프로덕트 담당자(product person)의 핵심 업무는 보통 애매한 걸 명확하게 만드는 거예요. 프로덕트 리더(product leader)나 프로덕트 매니저(product manager)의 역할을 생각해 보면, 모든 게 항상 불확실해요. 이 팀에서 내 역할이 뭔지? 우리가 해결하려는 문제는 뭔지? 타겟 고객은 누구인지? 어떤 프로토타입(prototype)이 이 문제를 해결할지? 이런 것들이니까요. 결국 말 그대로 모든 걸 다 다루는 거예요.
text_zh: 产品人员的核心工作就是把模糊不清的东西变得清晰明了。你想想产品负责人或者产品经理(product manager)的工作，什么都是模糊的——我在团队里到底是干什么的？我们要解决什么问题？目标用户是谁？什么样的原型(prototype)能解决这个具体问题？可以说是方方面面都不清楚。
text_es: El trabajo fundamental de alguien en producto es básicamente convertir lo que no está claro en algo que sí lo esté. Y si te pones a pensar en el rol de un líder de producto o un product manager, todo es ambiguo todo el tiempo. O sea, ¿cuál es mi papel en este equipo? ¿Qué problema estamos resolviendo? ¿Quién es nuestro cliente objetivo? ¿Qué prototipo va a resolver este problema específico? Literalmente es todo.
context: Lenny asks Lane about the core principles he's identified for great product managers. Lane shares his unifying thesis that the fundamental job of any product person is to turn ambiguity into clarity. He explains that product managers constantly face unclear situations - from understanding their role to identifying problems and solutions - and their primary skill must be spotting ambiguity and making it clear.
vocabulary_highlights: turn ambiguity into clarity, literally everything

speaker: Lane Shackleton
speaker_expertise: Product Management, Team Building, Product Strategy
text: Goals with good intentions don't work. I really need to give a common example. A really common example is teams that are trying to learn about customers or do research. And one thing I've observed is a team may have a goal like an OKR of talking to 10 customers this quarter and they may or may not hit that OKR. And then if you watch closely, the next quarter, they may not have a goal of talking to customers anymore.
text_ko: 좋은 의도로 세운 목표는 잘 작동하지 않아요. 예를 들어볼게요. 고객에 대해 배우거나 연구를 하려는 팀이 흔한 예인데요. 제가 관찰한 바로는, 어떤 팀이 이번 분기에 고객 10명과 이야기하겠다는 OKR을 세우고, 그 목표를 달성할 수도 있고 못할 수도 있어요. 그런데 자세히 보면, 다음 분기에는 고객과 이야기하겠다는 목표가 아예 없어지는 경우가 많아요.
text_zh: 光有好想法的目标是没用的。我得举个特别常见的例子。最典型的就是那些想了解客户、做调研的团队。我发现很多团队会定个OKR目标，比如这个季度要跟10个客户聊聊，但他们不一定能完成这个OKR。然后你仔细观察就会发现，下个季度他们可能就不再把跟客户聊天当目标了。
text_es: Los objetivos con buenas intenciones no funcionan. Necesito dar un ejemplo muy común. Un ejemplo súper típico son los equipos que están tratando de conocer mejor a sus clientes o hacer investigación. Y algo que he visto es que un equipo puede tener un objetivo como un OKR de hablar con 10 clientes este trimestre y puede que lo logren o puede que no. Y si te fijas bien, el siguiente trimestre, es posible que ya ni tengan como meta hablar con clientes.
context: Lenny asks about Lane's principle of "systems not goals." Lane explains this concept using Jerry Seinfeld's approach to comedy writing, where the system (writing for an hour every morning) matters more than the goal (building up material). He argues that teams often set well-intentioned goals like OKRs to talk to customers, but without a consistent system, these goals are inconsistently achieved and abandoned.
vocabulary_highlights: goals with good intentions, watch closely, may or may not

speaker: Lane Shackleton
speaker_expertise: Product Management, Team Building, Product Strategy
text: Instead of being obsessed with the goal, be obsessed with the system that gets you there. And so the phrase I sometimes use is goals with good intentions don't work. And to draw a contrast, that's just really different than a team that has some default on system for talking to customers. Every few times a week they're talking to customers for whatever reason.
text_ko: 목표(goal)에 집착하기보다는 그 목표로 데려다 주는 시스템(system)에 집착하세요. 그래서 제가 가끔 하는 말이 “의도만 좋은 목표(goal)는 통하지 않아요.”라고 해요. 반대로 고객과 대화하는 기본적인 시스템(system)을 갖춘 팀은 완전히 달라요. 일주일에 몇 번씩이라도 특별한 이유가 없어도 꾸준히 고객과 대화하기 때문이에요.
text_zh: 别老盯着目标不放，应该专注于能带你达成目标的体系。我经常说的一句话就是：光有好想法的目标是没用的。形成对比的是，那些真正厉害的团队都有一套默认的客户沟通体系。他们每周都会定期跟客户聊几次，不管是什么原因。
text_es: En lugar de obsesionarte con la meta, obsesiónate with el sistema que te lleva ahí. Y por eso a veces digo que las metas con buenas intenciones no funcionan. Y para hacer un contraste, eso es muy diferente a un equipo que tiene por defecto un sistema para hablar con los clientes. Varias veces a la semana están hablando con clientes, por la razón que sea.
context: Lane continues explaining his "systems not goals" principle by contrasting teams that set customer research goals versus teams that have systematic approaches. He describes how at Coda they had a "default on" system where customers came in every Friday, forcing the team to always have something to show and creating consistent customer interaction rather than sporadic goal-driven research.
vocabulary_highlights: be obsessed with, draw a contrast, default on system, for whatever reason

speaker: Lane Shackleton
speaker_expertise: Product Management, Team Building, Product Strategy
text: We basically have five levels and we call them role stages and they go from apprentice to principal. So apprentice is ... Rope analogy here is learns about rope. Practitioner is can tie basic knots, shown complex knots. Given a problem, they can do it. Career is you can calculate rope strength. You know a lot about knots. Principal is basically invented nylon.
text_ko: 우리는 기본적으로 다섯 단계가 있고, 이를 역할 단계(role stages)라고 부르며 견습(apprentice)부터 프린시펄(principal)까지 이어져요. 견습은 기본적으로 밧줄에 대해 배우는 단계예요. 실무자(practitioner)는 기본 매듭은 스스로 묶을 수 있고, 복잡한 매듭은 보여주면 따라 할 수 있어요. 문제를 주면 해결할 수 있어요. 커리어(career) 단계는 밧줄의 강도를 계산할 수 있고 매듭에 대해 아주 많이 아는 수준이에요. 프린시펄(principal)은 거의 나일론을 발명해낸 사람 같은 수준이에요.
text_zh: 我们基本上分五个级别，叫做角色阶段(role stages)，从学徒(apprentice)到首席专家(principal)。学徒就是...用绳子打个比方，就是刚开始了解绳子。从业者(practitioner)呢，能打基本的结，看懂复杂的结，给他个问题，他能解决。职业级(career)的话，你能算出绳子的强度，对各种结法都很懂。首席专家(principal)基本上就是发明尼龙的那种人。
text_es: Básicamente tenemos cinco niveles que llamamos etapas de rol (role stages) y van desde aprendiz hasta principal. Entonces, aprendiz es... usando la analogía de la cuerda, aprende sobre cuerdas. Practicante ya puede hacer nudos básicos, se le muestran nudos complejos. Si le das un problema, lo puede resolver. Carrera es que ya puedes calcular la resistencia de la cuerda. Sabes un montón sobre nudos. Principal básicamente es el que inventó el nylon.
context: Lenny asks about how Coda structures their career levels and performance reviews. Lane explains their unique five-level system that applies across all roles (product, design, engineering) rather than having separate ladders for each function. He uses a rope analogy to illustrate the progression from apprentice (learning basics) to principal (fundamental innovation), emphasizing that the highest level should be aspirational with an exceptionally high bar.
vocabulary_highlights: role stages, rope analogy, basic knots, calculate rope strength

speaker: Lane Shackleton
speaker_expertise: Product Management, Team Building, Product Strategy
text: The core insight here is that you want your teams to feel like they're building a cathedral and not laying bricks. And I think it's really, really easy to do when PMs are really busy on a day-to-day to just be one task after the other, really execution oriented and maybe not take the time to help the team take a broader frame, open the aperture a little bit and have a view of what the cathedral is.
text_ko: 핵심은 팀이 단순히 벽돌을 쌓는 사람이 아니라 대성당을 짓고 있다는 느낌을 받게 하는 거예요. 그런데 일상적으로 프로덕트 매니저들(PMs)이 너무 바쁘면, 정말정말 한 작업이 끝나면 바로 다음 작업으로 넘어가는 식으로 실행 위주로만 일하게 되기 쉬고, 팀이 좀 더 큰 관점에서 보게끔 잠깐 시야를 넓혀 주거나 대성당이 어떤 모습인지 보여줄 시간을 못 내는 경우가 많아요.
text_zh: 这里的核心洞察就是，你要让团队觉得他们是在建造大教堂，而不是在搬砖。我觉得产品经理(PM)每天忙得不可开交的时候，特别容易陷入这种状态——就是一个任务接一个任务地做，特别注重执行，可能就没时间帮团队拉开视野，放宽格局，让大家看到我们到底在建什么样的大教堂。
text_es: La clave aquí es que quieres que tus equipos sientan que están construyendo una catedral y no simplemente poniendo ladrillos. Y creo que es súper fácil que pase cuando los PMs están muy metidos en el día a día, van de tarea en tarea, muy enfocados en la ejecución, y a lo mejor no se toman el tiempo para ayudar al equipo a ver el panorama más amplio, abrir un poco la perspectiva y tener una visión de qué es esa catedral que están construyendo.
context: Lenny asks about Lane's "cathedrals, not bricks" principle. Lane shares the classic story of three people laying bricks - where one sees just moving bricks, another sees applying cement, but the third sees building a cathedral. He explains that product managers often get caught up in day-to-day execution without helping their teams understand the broader vision and purpose behind their work.
vocabulary_highlights: core insight, execution oriented, broader frame, open the aperture

speaker: Laura Modi
text: I think one of the biggest beliefs is that an ounce of naivety will be your biggest secret to success. And I think the word even naivety sometimes gets a bad rap, but naivety is the definition of creativity and innovation and canvas and white space and opportunity. And I definitely went into starting this company with a level of naivety to how regulated it was, to the stigma associated with it, to how hard it would be.
text_ko: 제 생각에는 많은 사람들이 '약간의 순진함'이야말로 성공의 비결이라는 믿음을 가지고 있어요. 순진함이라는 말이 때로는 안 좋게 들리기도 하지만, 사실 순진함은 창의력과 혁신, 빈 캔버스와 여백(white space), 그리고 기회의 본질이에요. 저도 이 회사를 시작할 때 규제가 얼마나 강한지, 관련된 낙인이 어떤지, 일이 얼마나 힘들지에 대해 어느 정도 순진한 상태로 들어갔어요.
text_zh: 我觉得最重要的一个理念就是，保持一点天真反而是成功的最大秘诀。虽然"天真"这个词有时候听起来不太好，但天真其实就是创造力、创新、无限可能和机会的代名词。我当初创办这家公司的时候，确实带着一种天真的心态——不太了解这个行业监管有多严，也没想到会有那么多偏见，更没料到会这么难做。
text_es: Creo que una de las creencias más importantes es que un poquito de ingenuidad va a ser tu mayor secreto para el éxito. Y pienso que la palabra ingenuidad a veces tiene mala fama, pero la ingenuidad es la definición de creatividad e innovación y de espacio en blanco y oportunidad. Y definitivamente empecé esta empresa con cierto nivel de ingenuidad sobre qué tan regulada estaba la industria, sobre el estigma que tenía, sobre qué tan difícil iba a ser.
context: Lenny asks Laura what she's learned about doing something completely new and different, given that she had never started a D2C business or formulated baby formula before launching Bobbie. Laura explains her philosophy that inexperience can actually be an advantage when entering a new industry. She shares how her lack of deep knowledge about the highly regulated formula industry allowed her to approach problems with fresh thinking rather than being constrained by traditional industry assumptions.
vocabulary_highlights: ounce of naivety, gets a bad rap, white space and opportunity
topics: Starting a Company, Decision Making, Strategy & Planning

speaker: Laura Modi
text: She pulls up her screen, she goes, 'Here's the dilemma. We are depleting inventory far quicker than our ability to replenish. And the customers keep coming.' You sit there and your first reaction is 'This is great. We're growing.' And she's like, 'It's not that great, actually, because here's what's going to happen. We are going to run out of product for the babies that are on Bobbie today.'
text_ko: 그녀가 화면을 띄우고 이렇게 말해요. "문제는 이거예요. 재고(inventory)가 보충(replenish)할 수 있는 속도보다 훨씬 빨리 줄어들고 있어요. 그런데 고객들이 계속 들어와요." 당신은 앉아서 첫 반응이 "좋다, 성장하고 있네"일 거예요. 근데 그녀가 "사실 그렇게 좋은 건 아니에요. 왜냐하면 결국 오늘 Bobbie를 먹고 있는 아기들에게 줄 제품이 다 떨어질 거예요."라고 해요.
text_zh: 她把屏幕调出来，说："问题来了，我们的库存消耗速度远远超过了补货速度，但客户还在源源不断地涌进来。" 你坐在那里，第一反应就是"这不是挺好的嘛，说明我们在增长啊。" 结果她说："其实没那么好，因为接下来会发生什么呢？那些已经在用Bobbie产品的宝宝们就要断粮了。"
text_es: Ella abre su pantalla y dice: "Mira, aquí está el problema. Se nos está acabando el inventario mucho más rápido de lo que podemos reponerlo. Y los clientes no paran de llegar." Te quedas ahí y tu primera reacción es "Esto está genial. Estamos creciendo." Y ella te dice: "Pues no está tan genial, la verdad, porque te voy a decir lo que va a pasar. Se nos va a acabar el producto para los bebés que ya están usando Bobbie."
context: Laura recounts a pivotal moment during the 2022 baby formula shortage crisis when Bobbie's head of growth identified a critical problem. While other formula companies were experiencing supply issues due to recalls, Bobbie was seeing explosive customer growth. However, their growth was outpacing their manufacturing capacity, creating a dangerous situation where they might not be able to serve existing customers who depended on their formula for their babies' nutrition.
vocabulary_highlights: depleting inventory, ability to replenish
topics: Growth & Marketing, Decision Making, Leadership & Management

speaker: Laura Modi
text: So we named the entire growth team, the slowth team. And I mean, they got creative. At some point we were emailing subscribers to nudge them to cancel because we were looking for a way to ensure that we could keep product, and my God, it was a mind-boggling moment.
text_ko: 그래서 우리는 전체 성장 팀을 '슬로스 팀'이라고 이름 지었어요. 정말 창의적이었죠. 어느 순간, 우리는 구독자들에게 이메일을 보내서 취소를 유도하기도 했어요. 제품을 유지할 방법을 찾고 있었거든요. 그 순간은 정말 놀라웠어요.
text_zh: 所以我们把整个增长团队改名叫"慢长团队"。我跟你说，他们真的是脑洞大开。有一段时间我们甚至给订阅用户发邮件，催他们取消订阅，因为我们想找个办法确保产品能继续做下去。我的天，那真是让人摸不着头脑的时刻。
text_es: Así que le pusimos al equipo completo de crecimiento, el equipo de "lentitud". Y te digo, se pusieron creativos. En un momento dado estábamos mandándoles emails a los suscriptores para empujarlos a que cancelaran porque buscábamos una manera de asegurar que pudiéramos mantener el producto, y Dios mío, fue un momento que te vuela la cabeza.
context: Laura describes how she managed team morale during the formula shortage crisis when Bobbie had to shut down their website to new customers for six months. She explains how they reframed the situation by creating the term 'slowth' (slow growth) to help employees whose jobs had suddenly shifted from driving growth to actively limiting it. The team had to get creative with unconventional tactics, including encouraging some existing subscribers to cancel their subscriptions to preserve inventory.
vocabulary_highlights: slowth team, nudge them to cancel, mind-boggling moment

speaker: Laura Modi
text: I think one of the biggest ones I would say is that you need to get to know people personally as much as you do professionally. And that was maybe something I also maybe took a little bit for granted at Airbnb. We had built a culture where people really personally loved each other. They loved working together.
text_ko: 제가 생각하기에 가장 중요한 것 중 하나는, 업무적으로 아는 만큼 개인적으로도 서로를 알아가야 한다는 점이에요. 그건 에어비앤비에 있을 때 저도 좀 당연하게 여겼던 부분인 것 같아요. 우리는 사람들이 개인적으로 서로를 진심으로 좋아하고 함께 일하는 걸 즐기는 문화를 만들어 왔어요.
text_zh: 我觉得最重要的一点就是，你既要了解同事的工作能力，也要了解他们这个人。这可能也是我在Airbnb时有点想当然的地方吧。我们当时建立的企业文化就是大家私下里都很喜欢彼此，工作起来也特别愉快。
text_es: Creo que una de las cosas más importantes que diría es que necesitas conocer a la gente a nivel personal tanto como a nivel profesional. Y eso fue algo que tal vez di por sentado en Airbnb. Habíamos construido una cultura donde la gente realmente se quería entre sí a nivel personal. Les encantaba trabajar juntos.
context: Lenny asks Laura about specific tactics for building strong company culture, referencing her earlier comments about culture being crucial to everything you do. Laura explains that one key element is developing personal relationships with team members, not just professional ones. She reflects on how Airbnb had successfully created this type of personal connection among employees, and discusses the challenge of replicating this in a fully remote company environment.
vocabulary_highlights: took a little bit for granted

speaker: Laura Modi
text: D2C isn't dead. Just the approach for how people did D2C is a bit dated. We should not be paying for every customer and we should be very careful that people aren't getting hooked on the drug that is paid marketing or performance marketing. And I think that drug, and then obviously as we start to see changes on the way certain performance works, it just becomes more expensive.
text_ko: D2C는 죽지 않았어요. 다만 사람들이 D2C를 해오던 접근 방식이 좀 구식이에요. 모든 고객마다 비용을 지불하면 안 되고, 유료 마케팅(paid marketing)이나 성과형 마케팅(performance marketing)에 중독되지 않도록 정말 조심해야 해요. 그리고 그 '약'은, 특히 어떤 성과형 채널의 작동 방식이 바뀌기 시작하면 자연스럽게 비용이 더 많이 드는 구조가 돼요.
text_zh: D2C(直接面向消费者)模式并没有死，只是以前那套做D2C的方法有点过时了。我们不应该为每个客户都花钱去获取，而且要特别小心，别让人对付费营销或效果营销(performance marketing)上瘾。我觉得这就像毒品一样，再加上现在效果营销的玩法在变，成本只会越来越高。
text_es: El D2C no está muerto. Lo que pasa es que la manera en que la gente hacía D2C ya está un poco anticuada. No deberíamos estar pagando por cada cliente y tenemos que tener mucho cuidado de que la gente no se vuelva adicta a esa droga que es el marketing pagado o el performance marketing. Y creo que esa droga, y después obviamente cuando empezamos a ver cambios en cómo funciona cierto performance, simplemente se vuelve más caro.
context: Lenny asks Laura about growing a direct-to-consumer (D2C) company, noting that D2C is considered very difficult with many attempts failing. Laura pushes back against the common narrative that 'D2C is dead,' arguing instead that traditional D2C approaches are outdated. She specifically criticizes the over-reliance on paid marketing and performance marketing, describing it as a 'drug' that companies become addicted to, especially as these channels become more expensive and less effective.
vocabulary_highlights: hooked on the drug, performance marketing

speaker: Laura Modi
text: I look for people who have the ability to make decisions and move fast and not get worried about the outcome. That is the biggest learning in a startup. The secret is momentum and just keeping momentum. And if we try and perfect everything, you just miss the boat.
text_ko: 저는 결정을 잘 내리고 빠르게 움직이면서 결과에 너무 연연하지 않는 사람들을 찾아요. 그건 스타트업(startup)에서 가장 큰 교훈이에요. 비결은 모멘텀(momentum)이고, 그 모멘텀을 계속 유지하는 거예요. 모든 걸 완벽하게 하려고 하면 그냥 기회를 놓쳐버려요.
text_zh: 我找人的时候，主要看他能不能快速决策，说干就干，而且不要老是纠结结果怎么样。这是做创业公司最大的收获。关键就是要保持势头，一直往前冲。如果什么事都想做到完美，机会早就跑了。
text_es: Busco gente que sepa tomar decisiones y moverse rápido sin quedarse preocupándose por lo que pueda pasar. Esa es la lección más grande en una startup. El secreto está en el momentum y mantener ese impulso. Y si nos ponemos a querer perfeccionar todo, simplemente se nos va el tren.
context: Lenny asks Laura what she looks for when hiring people, given her philosophy of hiring those without deep domain expertise. Laura explains that instead of technical skills, she prioritizes traits that support startup environments. She emphasizes the importance of people who can act quickly without getting paralyzed by uncertainty, noting that maintaining momentum is more critical than achieving perfection in a startup setting.
vocabulary_highlights: miss the boat

speaker: Laura Modi
text: Your job is not just to keep people going on momentum. Your job is to make momentum. And sometimes that momentum has to be manufactured. And that has been one of my biggest lessons on just how, as leaders and people starting companies, how do you force yourself? And sometimes when it's early on, you're actually just doing it to yourself, creating manufactured deadlines and launch dates.
text_ko: 당신의 일은 사람들을 그저 관성으로 움직이게 하는 것만이 아니에요. 당신의 일은 모멘텀(momentum)을 만들어내는 거예요. 그리고 그 모멘텀은 때로는 인위적으로 만들어야 할 때가 있어요. 제가 창업가이자 리더로서 배운 가장 큰 교훈 중 하나가 바로 '어떻게 스스로를 강제로 밀어붙이느냐'였어요. 초반에는 사실 스스로에게 인위적인 마감일(manufactured deadlines)이나 출시일(launch date)을 정해놓고 그렇게 자신을 움직이게 하는 경우가 많아요.
text_zh: 你的工作不只是让大家保持冲劲往前走，而是要创造这种冲劲。有时候这种动力得人为制造出来。这是我学到的最重要的一课——作为领导者和创业者，你怎么逼自己一把？特别是在早期阶段，其实就是跟自己较劲，人为设定一些截止日期和上线时间。
text_es: Tu trabajo no es solo mantener a la gente con inercia. Tu trabajo es crear esa inercia. Y a veces ese impulso hay que fabricarlo. Y esa ha sido una de mis lecciones más grandes sobre cómo, como líderes y gente que está empezando empresas, ¿cómo te obligas a ti mismo? Y a veces cuando estás empezando, en realidad solo te lo estás haciendo a ti mismo, creando fechas límite artificiales y fechas de lanzamiento.
context: Lenny asks Laura about other lessons she's learned about building a company, particularly around creating urgency and momentum. Laura explains that leaders must actively create momentum rather than just maintain it. She advocates for manufacturing artificial deadlines and launch dates as a way to force progress and prevent teams from getting stuck in endless planning or perfectionism, even when there's no external pressure requiring those specific timelines.
vocabulary_highlights: manufactured deadlines, force yourself

speaker: Laura Schaffer
text: So I wanted to run a test. I didn't have a team, I didn't have an engineering team yet and none of that stuff had built out. It was just me, myself and I. But like I said, I had started to build a little bit of trust and Andre, who I mentioned earlier who, because he was early employee and he had access to everything, one of those people, and he also was supportive of this and had similar haunches. And so like the dead of the night, and by that, I mean 7:00 PM or something, I'm pretty sure it was a Friday. We just asked for forgiveness and put these questions into the signup flow and ran as Navy test with a small group.
text_ko: 그래서 테스트를 해보고 싶었어요. 팀도 없었고, 엔지니어링 팀(engineering team)도 아직 없었고 그런 것들이 다 갖춰져 있지 않았어요. 그냥 저 혼자였죠. 근데 말했듯이 조금씩 신뢰는 쌓이고 있었고, 아까 언급한 안드레는 초창기 직원이라 모든 것에 접근할 수 있는 사람 중 하나였어요. 그도 이걸 지지했고 비슷한 직감이 있었어요. 그래서, 말하자면 한밤중에—여기서는 대충 저녁 7시쯤을 말하는 건데요, 아마 금요일이었던 것 같아요—우리는 일단 나중에 용서를 구하자고 하고 이 질문들을 회원가입 흐름(signup flow)에 넣어서 소규모 그룹 대상으로 네이비 테스트(Navy test)로 돌려봤어요.
text_zh: 所以我就想做个测试。当时我没有团队，也没有工程团队，什么都还没搭建起来，就我一个人。但是像我刚说的，我已经开始建立了一点信任，还有Andre，就是我之前提到的那个人，因为他是早期员工，什么权限都有，就是那种人，而且他也支持这个想法，有类似的直觉。然后在深更半夜，我是说晚上7点左右吧，应该是个周五。我们就先斩后奏，把这些问题加到注册流程里，然后对一小群人跑了个Navy测试。
text_es: Entonces quise hacer una prueba. No tenía equipo, todavía no tenía un equipo de ingeniería ni nada de eso armado. Era yo solito. Pero como te digo, ya había empezado a generar un poquito de confianza y André, que mencioné antes, como era empleado desde el principio y tenía acceso a todo, era de esas personas clave, y además apoyaba esto y tenía las mismas corazonadas. Entonces a altas horas de la noche, bueno, serían las 7 de la tarde o algo así, estoy seguro de que era viernes. Simplemente decidimos pedir perdón después y metimos estas preguntas en el flujo de registro y corrimos una prueba Navy con un grupo pequeño.
context: Lenny asks Laura about a surprising experiment result that changed her perspective on experimentation. Laura explains how she wanted to test adding questions to Twilio's signup flow, which was controversial because the company believed developers wanted a frictionless signup experience. Without official approval and lacking an engineering team, she convinced an early employee with system access to help her implement the questions in production late on a Friday evening as a guerrilla test with a small user group.
vocabulary_highlights: dead of the night, asked for forgiveness, Navy test, similar haunches

speaker: Laura Schaffer
text: I'm not kidding, an improved conversion. There's no personalization, nothing past it, just the questions. An improved conversion by like 5%, just improved signups. And it was one of those like, 'What? Okay, what is going on here?' And I actually dug into it, and what I found from just talking to a few customers once through the flow, I'm just learning about it. It was actually for folks, it was comforting.
text_ko: 농담 아니에요. 전환율(conversion rate)이 실제로 개선됐어요. 개인화(personalization) 같은 건 전혀 없었고, 그 다음 단계도 없었어요 — 그냥 질문들뿐이었어요. 전환이 대략 5% 정도 올랐고, 단순히 가입(signups)이 좀 늘어난 수준이었어요. '뭐지? 왜 이러지?' 싶은 상황이었죠. 그래서 제가 직접 파고들어봤더니, 고객 몇 명에게 그 흐름(flow)을 한 번 겪어보게 하고 얘기해본 것만으로도 배운 게 있었어요. 의외로 그건 사람들에게 오히려 안심이 되는 경험이었어요.
text_zh: 我没开玩笑，转化率(conversion)真的提升了。没有个性化，什么都没加，就是问了几个问题而已。转化率(conversion)提升了大概5%，注册用户就是增加了。当时我就想，'什么情况？这到底怎么回事？'然后我就深挖了一下，跟几个客户聊了聊整个流程，想搞明白是怎么回事。结果发现，对用户来说，这样做其实让他们觉得很安心。
text_es: No es broma, mejoramos la conversión. Sin personalización, sin nada después, solo las preguntas. Mejoramos la conversión como un 5%, simplemente más registros. Y fue una de esas situaciones de "¿Qué? Bueno, ¿qué está pasando aquí?" Y la verdad me puse a investigar a fondo, y lo que descubrí hablando con algunos clientes durante el proceso, aprendiendo sobre esto, fue que en realidad para la gente era tranquilizador.
context: Laura describes the shocking results of her guerrilla experiment at Twilio where she added signup questions. Instead of hurting conversion rates as everyone expected, the questions actually improved signups by 5%. This counterintuitive result prompted her to investigate by talking to customers who had gone through the new flow, discovering that the questions were actually making users feel more comfortable and confident about using the product.
vocabulary_highlights: dug into it, went through the flow

speaker: Laura Schaffer
text: When you think about it, when users are signing up for your product for the very first time, it's new. This is new, that means it's scary. They're expecting it to be difficult. They're anticipating that there's going to be friction and challenges and that they're not going to figure it out. Almost like looking for the bogeyman. And that's the headspace. It's often the headspace that any of us are in when we're doing something new for the first time like ooh, this could be very challenging.
text_ko: 생각해보면, 사용자가 제품에 처음 가입할 때 그건 완전히 새로워요. 새롭다는 건 무섭다는 뜻이에요. 어렵겠거니, 여기저기 마찰과 문제가 생길 거니, 내가 못 해내겠구나 하고 예상해요. 거의 문제거리를 먼저 찾아내려는 것처럼요. 그게 바로 그들의 마인드셋이에요. 사실 우리도 처음 해보는 일 앞에서는 ‘이거 꽤 어려울 수도 있겠다’ 하고 그런 마음가짐을 갖고 있는 경우가 많아요.
text_zh: 你想想啊，用户第一次注册你的产品的时候，这对他们来说是全新的东西。新的东西就意味着可怕嘛。他们心里就预设这肯定很难搞，肯定会遇到各种麻烦和挑战，肯定搞不明白。就像在找什么妖魔鬼怪似的。这就是他们的心理状态。其实我们任何人第一次做新事情的时候都是这种心态，心里想着"哎呀，这可能会很有挑战性"。
text_es: Cuando lo piensas bien, cuando los usuarios se registran en tu producto por primera vez, es algo nuevo para ellos. Es nuevo, y eso da miedo. Ya van esperando que sea difícil. Van anticipando que va a haber trabas y problemas, que no le van a agarrar la onda. Como si estuvieran buscando el coco. Y esa es la mentalidad que traen. Es la mentalidad en la que muchas veces estamos todos cuando hacemos algo nuevo por primera vez, como que "ay, esto puede estar muy complicado."
context: Laura explains the psychological insight she gained from her signup experiment at Twilio. She discovered that when users try a new product for the first time, they're naturally anxious and expecting difficulties. The signup questions actually helped alleviate this anxiety by giving users confidence that the product would support their specific needs and use cases, which is why conversion rates improved rather than decreased.
vocabulary_highlights: looking for the bogeyman, headspace

speaker: Laura Schaffer
text: The simple catchy thing I say is that ultimately the learning here is, bad friction is bad, and good friction is good. There's no such thing as it being simple. It's just all friction is bad, which is what I had assumed going into this.
text_ko: 제가 간단히 자주 하는 말은, 결국 여기서 배운 건 나쁜 마찰(friction)은 해롭고 좋은 마찰은 도움이 된다는 거예요. 이건 그렇게 단순한 문제가 아니고, '모든 마찰이 나쁘다'고만 보는 건 옳지 않아요 — 사실 저도 처음엔 그렇게 가정하고 들어갔어요.
text_zh: 我总结得很简单好记：关键是要明白，坏的摩擦就是不好，好的摩擦就是好的。不能简单地认为所有摩擦都是坏事——我一开始就是这么想的，以为只要有摩擦就不好，其实不是这样。
text_es: Lo que siempre digo de manera sencilla es que al final lo que aprendimos aquí es que la fricción mala es mala, y la fricción buena es buena. No es tan simple como pensar que toda fricción es mala, que era lo que yo creía al principio.
context: Laura summarizes the key insight from her Twilio signup experiment that challenged conventional wisdom about user experience. Rather than all friction being inherently harmful to conversion, she learned that there's a critical distinction between different types of friction. Good friction can actually improve user experience and conversion by addressing user psychology and concerns, while bad friction creates unnecessary barriers without providing value.
vocabulary_highlights: catchy thing I say

speaker: Laura Schaffer
text: So always better to be iterative so that you are letting failure work for you instead of having it be a trap that you fall into.
text_ko: 항상 반복적으로(iterative) 시도하는 편이 좋아요. 그래야 실패가 덫이 되는 대신 오히려 실패가 당신에게 도움이 돼요.
text_zh: 所以最好还是一步步来，让失败成为你的垫脚石，而不是掉进坑里爬不出来。
text_es: Siempre es mejor ir paso a paso, iterando, para que los fracasos te sirvan en lugar de convertirse en una trampa en la que caes.
context: Lenny asks Laura whether it's better to redesign entire experiences or iterate piece by piece when running experiments. Laura advocates for iterative approaches, explaining that roughly 80% of product hypotheses fail according to research from companies like Netflix and Microsoft. By testing small changes incrementally, teams can learn from failures quickly and use those insights as guidance rather than investing heavily in complete redesigns that are more likely to fail entirely.
vocabulary_highlights: letting failure work for you, be a trap that you fall into

speaker: Laura Schaffer
text: If it's not embarrassing, you've gone too far. Got to be embarrassing. The first thing, that was embarrassing, kicking people out, onboarding, spend all this money and whatever to get them into your center flow, and then the first thing we do, get out of here. That's nuts. But if it hadn't validated, that would've been a very cheap but very valuable learning.
text_ko: 부끄럽지 않다면, 뭔가 잘못된 거예요. 부끄러워야 해요. 처음에 부끄러운 건, 사람들을 쫓아내는 거예요. 온보딩(onboarding)도 하고, 돈도 많이 쓰고, 그 사람들을 우리 시스템에 맞추려고 하는데, 첫 번째로 하는 게 '나가세요'라니, 말도 안 돼요. 하지만 만약 그게 검증되지 않았다면, 그건 정말 값싼, 하지만 아주 소중한 배움이었을 거예요.
text_zh: 如果你觉得不丢脸，那说明你做得还不够。一定要让人觉得尴尬才行。第一件事确实挺尴尬的，把人踢出去——你知道吧，我们花了那么多钱和精力让他们进入我们的核心流程(center flow)，结果第一件事就是告诉他们"你们走吧"。这听起来就很疯狂对不对。但如果这个假设没得到验证的话，那这个教训虽然代价不高，但价值可就大了。
text_es: Si no te da un poco de vergüenza, es que ya te pasaste. Tiene que dar vergüenza. Lo primero que hicimos, que sí daba vergüenza, fue echar a la gente, después de todo el proceso de incorporación (onboarding), gastamos un montón de dinero y lo que fuera para meterlos en nuestro flujo central, y luego lo primero que hacemos es decirles "lárguense de aquí". Está loco. Pero si no se hubiera validado, habría sido un aprendizaje muy barato pero súper valioso.
context: Laura explains her philosophy about iterative experimentation and the importance of launching embarrassingly simple first versions. She gives an example of redirecting users out of Twilio's onboarding flow to test a hypothesis about developer psychology with phone numbers. While this approach seemed counterintuitive and embarrassing, it provided cheap validation before investing in building a more polished solution.
vocabulary_highlights: gone too far, kicked people out, get out of here

speaker: Laura Schaffer
text: If you are a company that is providing, that requires developers to build, you must invest in self-serve experiences in order to effectively convert your audience. And you should be thinking of them, something akin your self-serve function and growth folks, someone akin to Salesforce because your developers are not going to accept sales coming in and trying to convert them at that stage.
text_ko: 개발자들이 직접 구축해야 하는 제품을 제공하는 회사라면, 잠재 고객을 효과적으로 전환하려면 셀프 서비스 경험(self-serve experiences)에 투자해야 해요. 그리고 이걸 담당하는 건 세일즈포스(Salesforce)식의 직접 영업이 아니라, 셀프 서비스 담당자(self-serve function)나 성장팀(growth folks)처럼 사용자가 스스로 써보고 전환되게 만드는 쪽으로 생각해야 해요. 개발자들은 그 단계에서 영업이 와서 설득하는 걸 받아들이지 않을 거예요.
text_zh: 如果你们公司是做开发者产品的，就必须要投资做好自助服务体验，这样才能有效地转化你的用户。你应该把自助服务功能和增长团队看得跟Salesforce一样重要，因为开发者们在那个阶段是不会接受销售人员主动联系他们做转化的。
text_es: Si eres una empresa que ofrece servicios para desarrolladores, tienes que invertir sí o sí en experiencias de autoservicio para convertir bien a tu audiencia. Y deberías pensar en algo parecido a tu función de autoservicio y la gente de crecimiento, algo como lo que hace Salesforce, porque los desarrolladores no van a aceptar que llegue el equipo de ventas a tratar de convertirlos en esa etapa.
context: Lenny asks Laura about advice for building products that sell to developers. Laura explains that developers have unique psychology because they're personally responsible when tools they choose fail - it affects their reputation, team trust, and potentially their job. This high-stakes environment means developers need to prove tools work themselves through hands-on building before committing, making self-serve experiences critical for developer-focused companies.
vocabulary_highlights: something akin to, at that stage

speaker: Lauren Ipsen
speaker_expertise: Product Management, Team Building, Leadership Development
text: So, got into exec search, was really focused early on on consumer mobile build outs. Was doing a lot of work with Twitter and Reddit and TaskRabbit and Nextdoor, Postmates, you name it, and that was probably 85% of the work I was doing. And then as, on the agency side, 15% was obscure, autonomous helicopters selling into the Department of Defense and then retail and robotics, and it was all very fascinating, but for me, who has wicked bad ADD, it was amazing to be able to be so stimulated by so many different industries and feel like I couldn't really master this.
text_ko: 그래서 임원 서치(exec search) 쪽으로 들어갔는데, 초반에는 컨슈머 모바일 확장(consumer mobile build outs)에 정말 집중했어요. Twitter랑 Reddit, TaskRabbit, Nextdoor, Postmates 같은 데랑 많이 일했는데, 그게 아마 제 일의 85%쯤이었어요. 에이전시 쪽에서는 나머지 15%가 좀 생소한 쪽이었고, 자율 비행 헬리콥터를 국방부(Department of Defense)에 파는 일도 있었고 소매업이나 로보틱스 관련 일도 있었어요. 다들 되게 흥미로웠지만, 저처럼 주의력결핍장애(ADD)가 심한 사람한테는 이렇게 다양한 산업에서 계속 자극을 받는 게 엄청 신나면서도 한편으론 이걸 다 완전히 마스터하진 못하겠다는 느낌이 들더라고요.
text_zh: 所以呢，我就进了猎头这行，一开始主要专注做消费者移动端的团队搭建。当时跟Twitter、Reddit、TaskRabbit、Nextdoor、Postmates这些公司合作特别多，你能想到的基本都有，这大概占了我85%的工作量。然后呢，在代理这块，剩下15%都是些比较冷门的项目，比如卖给国防部的自主直升机，还有零售和机器人相关的，都挺有意思的。但对我这种严重ADD(注意力缺陷)的人来说，能接触这么多不同行业确实很刺激，但也让我觉得好像哪个都没法真正精通。
text_es: Entonces, me metí en búsqueda ejecutiva, y al principio me enfoqué mucho en el desarrollo de aplicaciones móviles para consumidores. Trabajaba bastante con Twitter, Reddit, TaskRabbit, Nextdoor, Postmates, ya sabes, de todo. Y eso era como el 85% de lo que hacía. Y después, del lado de la agencia, el 15% restante eran cosas súper específicas: helicópteros autónomos que se vendían al Departamento de Defensa, retail, robótica... todo súper interesante. Pero para mí, que tengo un déficit de atención brutal, era increíble poder estar tan estimulado por tantas industrias diferentes, aunque sentía que no podía realmente dominar esto.
context: Lenny asks Lauren to walk through her career background and how she got to where she is now. Lauren explains her early career in executive search, describing how she worked across different industries from consumer tech companies to defense contractors. She mentions having ADD and how the variety of work kept her engaged and stimulated across multiple sectors.
vocabulary_highlights: exec search, consumer mobile build outs, wicked bad ADD

speaker: Lauren Ipsen
speaker_expertise: Product Management, Team Building, Leadership Development
text: I think especially for founders that haven't hired for this caliber of talent in the past, it's really easy to be distracted by shiny objects and look at huge names. You want to find the CPOs of Google and YouTube or what have you because that seems like it would be such an incredible opportunity for brand recognition. And to an extent, it is. But the fact of the matter is, oftentimes those individuals are pretty far from the work and have a great team of executors that they've put into place that are actually the ones that are in the weeds.
text_ko: 특히 창업자분들 중에서 이런 수준의 인재를 채용해본 적이 없는 분들은 화려한 이름에 쉽게 눈이 가는 경우가 많아요. 구글이나 유튜브의 CPO 같은 사람들을 찾고 싶어 하시는데, 그게 브랜드 인지도를 높일 수 있는 멋진 기회처럼 보이거든요. 실제로 그런 면도 있긴 해요. 하지만 사실, 그런 분들은 종종 실제 일에서 멀리 떨어져 있고, 그들이 세운 훌륭한 팀이 실제로 현장에서 일하는 경우가 많아요.
text_zh: 我觉得特别是那些以前没招过这种级别人才的创始人，特别容易被那些闪闪发光的大名头给迷住眼。你就想着要去挖Google、YouTube的CPO啊什么的，觉得这对品牌认知度来说简直是天大的机会。确实，在某种程度上是这样的。但事实是什么呢？这些大牛往往已经脱离具体工作很久了，他们手下有一帮很能干的执行团队，真正在一线干活、深入细节的其实是这些人。
text_es: Creo que especialmente para los fundadores que nunca han contratado talento de este nivel, es súper fácil distraerse con cosas que brillan y fijarse solo en los nombres grandes. Quieren conseguir a los CPOs de Google y YouTube o lo que sea porque parece que sería una oportunidad increíble para el reconocimiento de marca. Y hasta cierto punto, lo es. Pero la realidad es que muchas veces esos individuos están bastante alejados del trabajo del día a día y tienen un equipazo de ejecutores que han puesto en su lugar, que son los que realmente están metidos en la trinchera haciendo el trabajo pesado.
context: Lenny asks about the biggest mistake founders make when hiring their first senior product leader. Lauren explains that inexperienced founders often chase big names from famous companies like Google or YouTube for brand recognition, but warns this can backfire. She points out that senior executives at large companies are often removed from hands-on work and rely on their teams to execute, making them potentially less suitable for early-stage companies that need someone who can dive into tactical work.
vocabulary_highlights: distracted by shiny objects, this caliber of talent, far from the work, in the weeds

speaker: Lauren Ipsen
speaker_expertise: Product Management, Team Building, Leadership Development
text: Just because this is the best talent, that doesn't necessarily mean they are the best talent for this role today. So to double down on that, say you are hiring and you know you're going to start hiring a senior product leader, what is it that you suggest founders nail down and iron out when they're kicking off the hiring process, either on their own or with a recruiter?
text_ko: 단지 최고의 인재라는 이유만으로 그 사람이 지금 이 역할에 가장 적합하다고는 할 수 없어요. 그 점을 더 강조하자면, 채용을 시작해서 시니어 프로덕트 리더(senior product leader)를 뽑으려고 할 때, 창업자들(founders)이 직접 하든 리크루터(recruiter)와 함께 하든 채용 과정 초기에 무엇을 확실히 정리하고 확정해놔야 한다고 조언하시겠어요?
text_zh: 就算是顶尖人才，也不见得就适合现在这个岗位。在这个基础上我想再问一下，比如说你要招一个资深的产品负责人，你觉得创始人在启动招聘流程的时候，不管是自己招还是找猎头，都应该先把哪些事情想清楚、搞定？
text_es: Solo porque este sea el mejor talento disponible, no significa necesariamente que sea el mejor talento para este puesto en este momento. Entonces, para profundizar en eso, digamos que estás contratando y sabes que vas a empezar a buscar un líder senior de producto, ¿qué les sugieres a los fundadores que definan bien y tengan claro desde el inicio del proceso de contratación, ya sea que lo hagan solos o con un reclutador?
context: Lauren is discussing the importance of hiring the right person for the specific role and stage of the company, rather than just hiring the most impressive candidate on paper. She emphasizes that the best talent in general may not be the best talent for a particular role at a particular time. This follows her earlier point about founders being distracted by big names from major tech companies.
vocabulary_highlights: double down on, nail down and iron out, kicking off

speaker: Lauren Ipsen
speaker_expertise: Product Management, Team Building, Leadership Development
text: Regardless of whether or not you're hiring, you should always be keeping a pulse on the market. That is the most important thing. And I think that should be the case for both candidates and folks that are hiring. Like, you never want to put yourself in a position where you have no idea what good looks like, whether that's from a company standpoint or from a candidate standpoint.
text_ko: 채용을 하고 있든 안 하고 있든 항상 시장을 주시하고 있어야 해요. 그게 가장 중요해요. 이건 지원자든 채용하는 사람(혹은 회사)이든 모두에게 해당된다고 생각해요. 회사 관점이든 지원자 관점이든 ‘좋은 모습이 무엇인지’를 전혀 모르는 상태로 자신을 두면 안 되거든요.
text_zh: 不管你现在招不招人，都要时刻关注市场动态，这是最重要的。我觉得求职者和招聘方都应该这样。你绝对不能让自己陷入那种完全不知道什么是好标准的状况，不管是从公司角度还是从候选人角度来说都是这样。
text_es: Sin importar si estás contratando o no, siempre tienes que estar al tanto de cómo está el mercado. Eso es lo más importante. Y creo que eso aplica tanto para los candidatos como para los que están contratando. O sea, nunca te quieres meter en una situación donde no tienes ni idea de qué es lo que está bien, ya sea desde el punto de vista de la empresa o desde el punto de vista del candidato.
context: Lenny asks what founders should do when they know they will hire a head of product in the future to set themselves up for success. Lauren emphasizes the importance of always staying informed about the talent market, even when not actively hiring. She explains that both hiring managers and job candidates should maintain awareness of which companies are thriving and which individuals are performing well in their organizations.
vocabulary_highlights: keeping a pulse on the market, what good looks like

speaker: Lauren Ipsen
speaker_expertise: Product Management, Team Building, Leadership Development
text: I think breadth is incredibly important. It's so critical, especially if someone has an end goal of wanting to step into a product leadership role to have been able to have touched lots of different components, as opposed to specializing in one specific thing. So I would say that's very important, to be able to make sure that you're maximizing opportunities for yourself down the road.
text_ko: 저는 폭넓은 경험이 정말 중요하다고 생각해요. 특히 제품 리더십 역할(product leadership role)을 목표로 한다면, 한 가지에만 전문화되기보다 여러 영역을 직접 다뤄본 경험이 있는 게 훨씬 도움이 돼요. 그래서 앞으로 기회를 최대한 살리려면 가능한 많은 경험을 쌓는 게 중요해요.
text_zh: 我觉得知识面广特别重要。这一点太关键了，尤其是如果有人最终想做到产品负责人的位置，那就得接触过各种不同的模块，而不是只专精某一个领域。所以我觉得这很重要，要确保给自己未来创造更多的机会。
text_es: Creo que tener amplitud de experiencia es súper importante. Es clave, sobre todo si alguien tiene como meta llegar a un puesto de liderazgo en producto, haber podido tocar muchos componentes diferentes, en lugar de especializarse en una sola cosa. Así que yo diría que eso es muy importante, asegurarte de que estás maximizando las oportunidades para ti más adelante.
context: Lenny asks what product leaders and PMs should focus on to give themselves the most opportunity in their career. Lauren emphasizes the importance of gaining broad experience across different areas of product work rather than becoming overly specialized in one area. She explains this is particularly crucial for those who aspire to product leadership roles, as breadth of experience helps maximize future career opportunities.
vocabulary_highlights: step into a product leadership role, touched lots of different components, maximizing opportunities

speaker: Lauren Ipsen
speaker_expertise: Product Management, Team Building, Leadership Development
text: There's also something to be said about staying somewhere too long though. And I will say that. I think sometimes you find people that are almost loyal to a fault, and companies have tanked and all executives have left and the writing's on the wall, and they're holding onto the fact that they were hired by a really good guy or gal and they want to make it work because they care about the human being, and I think sometimes in your career you do have to be a little bit more selfish and think about what's going to be best for you in the long haul.
text_ko: 한곳에 너무 오래 머무르는 것도 문제라는 말이 있어요. 솔직히 말하면, 가끔 충성심이 지나쳐서 오히려 독이 되는 사람들을 보게 돼요. 회사가 망해가고 임원들이 다 떠나가서 상황이 뻔히 보이는데도, ‘나를 뽑아준 정말 좋은 사람’이라는 이유로 그 사람을 위해서라도 어떻게든 버티려고 하는 거죠. 사람을 아끼는 마음은 이해되지만, 경력에서는 때로는 좀 더 자신에게 이기적일 필요가 있고 장기적으로 자기에게 무엇이 최선인지 생각해야 해요.
text_zh: 不过待在一个地方太久也有问题。我得说，有时候你会发现有些人忠诚得过了头，公司都快完蛋了，高管都跑光了，墙上的字都写得明明白白的了，他们还死抓着不放，就因为当初是个不错的老板招的他们，想着要让事情成功，因为他们在乎那个人。我觉得有时候在职业生涯中，你确实得自私一点，多想想从长远来看什么对你最好。
text_es: Pero también hay que decir algo sobre quedarse demasiado tiempo en un lugar. Y lo voy a decir. Creo que a veces te encuentras con gente que es leal hasta el punto de hacerse daño, y las empresas se han ido a pique y todos los ejecutivos se han largado y está clarísimo lo que va a pasar, pero ellos siguen aferrados al hecho de que los contrató alguien muy bueno y quieren que funcione porque les importa esa persona, y creo que a veces en tu carrera tienes que ser un poquito más egoísta y pensar en lo que va a ser mejor para ti a largo plazo.
context: Lenny asks about how often people should move between companies to optimize for future opportunities. Lauren discusses the balance between job hopping (which looks bad) and staying too long at a company. She warns against being 'loyal to a fault' when a company is clearly failing - staying at a sinking ship out of personal loyalty to the person who hired you can hurt your career in the long run.
vocabulary_highlights: loyal to a fault, companies have tanked, the writing's on the wall, in the long haul

speaker: Lauren Ipsen
speaker_expertise: Product Management, Team Building, Leadership Development
text: So I think it's essential that you remember that this is another human being on the other end of things and that you should treat them with the same level of respect that you would expect to be treated. This has become even more apparent now that I have gone through some of my own recruiting cycles where I was looking for different jobs, and a transactional recruiting call just will rub you so the wrong way and will make you want to put things on your resume like I just alluded to that say things like, 'Whatever at Reddit,' or what have you because you just don't want to deal with it.
text_ko: 그래서 이건 정말 중요한 것 같아요. 상대방도 결국 다른 인간이라는 걸 잊지 말고, 내가 받고 싶은 만큼의 존중을 그들에게도 해줘야 해요. 요즘 제가 여러 번 채용 과정을 겪으면서 이게 더 확실해졌어요. 거래 같은 느낌의 채용 전화는 정말 기분이 나쁘고, 그래서 이력서에 '레딧에서 뭐든지' 같은 식으로 적고 싶어지게 만들죠. 그냥 그런 상황을 피하고 싶어지는 거예요.
text_zh: 所以我觉得特别重要的一点是，你得记住电话那头也是个活生生的人，你得用你希望别人对待你的方式去对待他们。我自己也经历过找工作的招聘流程后，这一点就更明显了。那种特别公事公办的招聘电话真的会让你很反感，甚至想在简历上写一些我刚才提到的那种话，比如"在Reddit随便干了点什么"之类的，因为你就是不想搭理这种事儿。
text_es: Entonces creo que es fundamental que recuerdes que del otro lado hay otra persona, un ser humano, y que la tienes que tratar con el mismo respeto con el que tú esperas que te traten. Esto se me hizo aún más claro ahora que he pasado por mis propios procesos de búsqueda de trabajo, donde yo era el que buscaba otros puestos, y una llamada de reclutamiento súper transaccional te cae pésimo y te dan ganas de poner cosas en tu currículum como las que acabo de mencionar, tipo "Lo que sea en Reddit" o algo así, porque simplemente no quieres lidiar con eso.
context: Lenny asks what recruiters often do wrong when trying to attract great product talent. Lauren emphasizes that recruiters must remember they're dealing with real people, not just candidates to place. She shares her personal experience of being recruited and how transactional, impersonal recruiting calls are so off-putting that they make people want to hide their real job titles on LinkedIn to avoid being contacted by recruiters.
vocabulary_highlights: transactional recruiting call, rub you so the wrong way, just alluded to

speaker: Lauryn Isford
text: So, experimentation is a really big part, growth culture, growth hacking culture, PLG culture, growth marketing culture, any kind of growth, at least in my sphere, and sometimes teams can be really, really dependent on experimentation when trying to grow a business. A great example of this would be consumer growth at scale.
text_ko: 그래서 실험(experimentation)은 성장 문화(growth culture), 그로스 해킹 문화(growth hacking culture), 제품 주도 성장 문화(PLG culture), 그로스 마케팅 문화(growth marketing culture) 같은 모든 성장 쪽에서 정말 큰 부분이에요, 적어도 제 영역에서는요. 그리고 팀들이 사업을 키우려고 할 때 실험에 정말 많이 의존하기도 해요. 좋은 예가 바로 대규모 소비자 성장(consumer growth at scale)이에요.
text_zh: 所以说，实验这块儿真的特别重要，不管是增长文化、增长黑客(growth hacking)文化、PLG文化，还是增长营销文化，反正在我接触的增长领域里，团队有时候会非常依赖实验来推动业务增长。最典型的例子就是大规模的消费者增长。
text_es: Entonces, la experimentación es súper importante en toda la cultura de crecimiento, la cultura de growth hacking, la cultura PLG, la cultura de growth marketing, cualquier tipo de crecimiento, al menos en mi ámbito, y a veces los equipos pueden volverse súper dependientes de la experimentación cuando están tratando de hacer crecer un negocio. Un ejemplo perfecto de esto sería el crecimiento de consumidores a gran escala.
context: Lenny asks Lauryn about her contrarian take on experimentation - that people run experiments too often and maybe not everything should be an experiment. Lauryn begins explaining how experimentation has become deeply embedded in growth culture across different business models. She's setting up her argument that teams can become overly dependent on A/B testing when trying to grow their business.
vocabulary_highlights: growth hacking culture, PLG culture, at least in my sphere, consumer growth at scale

speaker: Lauryn Isford
text: So, with all that said, generally my advice is to experiment when you need to and to primarily see it as a risk mitigation tactic when you're making dramatic changes and to let the product development process do more work. So, spend more time with customers, be more rigorous in understanding precisely what problem you're solving, get mocks in front of people and see how they react, and hopefully have more conviction than you otherwise would when you ship something.
text_ko: 결론적으로 제 일반적인 조언은, 필요한 경우엔 실험해 보되 특히 큰 변화를 할 때는 그걸 주로 리스크 완화 전략(risk mitigation tactic)으로 보시고 제품 개발 프로세스(product development process)에 더 맡기라는 거예요. 그러니까 고객과 더 많은 시간을 보내고, 내가 정확히 어떤 문제를 해결하려는지 더 엄격하게 파악하고, 목업(mockup)을 사람들 앞에 보여 반응을 보고, 출시(ship)할 때는 평소보다 더 확신을 가지고 내보내세요.
text_zh: 所以总的来说，我的建议是该做实验的时候就做实验，主要把它当作一种风险控制手段，特别是当你要做大改动的时候。然后让产品开发流程发挥更大作用。也就是说，多花时间跟客户接触，更严谨地去搞清楚你到底要解决什么问题，把原型图(mock)拿给用户看看他们的反应，这样当你真正发布产品的时候，心里会更有底。
text_es: Entonces, dicho todo esto, mi consejo generalmente es que experimenten cuando sea necesario y que lo vean principalmente como una táctica para mitigar riesgos cuando están haciendo cambios importantes, y que dejen que el proceso de desarrollo del producto haga más trabajo. O sea, pasen más tiempo con los clientes, sean más rigurosos para entender exactamente qué problema están resolviendo, pongan los mockups frente a la gente y vean cómo reaccionan, y ojalá tengan más convicción de la que tendrían normalmente cuando lancen algo.
context: Lauryn explains her philosophy on when to run experiments versus when to skip them. She argues that experiments should primarily be used for risk mitigation rather than precision in measuring impact. Her main point is that teams should invest more time in customer research, problem validation, and product development processes to build conviction before shipping, rather than relying on A/B tests for every decision.
vocabulary_highlights: risk mitigation tactic, let the product development process do more work, get mocks in front of people, have more conviction
topics: Growth & Marketing, Decision Making, Product Management

speaker: Lauryn Isford
text: However, I do think you can build a different culture, and the only way to escape the trap of experimenting everything is to have a very intentional culture about doing right by customers and doing the right thing for the business. A growth team or a growth org exists in service of improving the business and delivering results for the business, and whether or not you measure those precisely in an A/B test, you still shipped them or you didn't.
text_ko: 하지만 저는 다른 문화를 만들 수 있다고 생각해요. 모든 걸 다 실험해 보는 함정에서 벗어나려면 고객에게 옳은 일을 하고 비즈니스에 맞는 결정을 내리는 데 대해 아주 의도적인 문화가 필요해요. 그로스 팀(growth team)이나 그로스 조직(growth org)은 비즈니스를 개선하고 성과를 내기 위해 존재하고, 그걸 A/B 테스트(A/B test)로 정확히 측정하든 안 하든 결국 출시했느냐 못 했느냐는 분명해요.
text_zh: 不过我觉得你是可以建立一种不同的文化的，要想摆脱什么都要测试一遍这个坑，唯一的办法就是要有一种很明确的文化理念——就是要真正为客户着想，为公司做正确的事情。增长团队(growth team)或者增长组织(growth org)存在的意义就是为了改善业务，为公司带来实实在在的结果。不管你有没有通过A/B测试(A/B test)精确地衡量这些结果，反正你要么上线了，要么没上线，就这么简单。
text_es: Sin embargo, sí creo que puedes construir una cultura diferente, y la única manera de escapar de la trampa de estar experimentando con todo es tener una cultura muy intencional enfocada en hacer lo correcto para los clientes y hacer lo que conviene al negocio. Un equipo de crecimiento (growth team) o una organización de crecimiento existe para servir al mejoramiento del negocio y entregar resultados concretos, y no importa si los mides de manera precisa en una prueba A/B o no, al final del día los entregaste o no los entregaste.
context: Lenny asks how to work in a culture that heavily values experimentation and uses A/B test results for performance reviews and team status. Lauryn responds that it's possible to build a different culture by being intentional about prioritizing customer value and business impact over precise measurement. She argues that the real question is whether you delivered results, not whether you measured them precisely through experiments.
vocabulary_highlights: escape the trap, very intentional culture, doing right by customers, in service of improving the business
topics: Leadership & Management, Growth & Marketing, Decision Making

speaker: Lauryn Isford
text: We were working on activation for a few years before I arrived at Airtable. There was already an awesome activation team, hard at work. Overall, the investments we made in onboarding over about a six to eight month period that included the wizard, The Mole with ongoing education, and also some personalization together drove a 20% lift in activation rate for Airtable.
text_ko: 제가 Airtable에 합류하기 전 몇 년 동안 이미 액티베이션(activation) 작업을 해오고 있었고, 훌륭한 액티베이션(activation) 팀이 열심히 일하고 있었어요. 전반적으로 약 6~8개월 동안 온보딩(onboarding)에 투자한 것들—위자드(wizard), The Mole과 지속적인 교육(ongoing education), 그리고 개인화(personalization)—이 합쳐져 Airtable의 활성화율(activation rate)을 약 20% 끌어올렸어요.
text_zh: 我来Airtable之前，团队已经在做用户激活(activation)好几年了。当时就有一个特别棒的激活团队在那儿拼命干活。总的来说，我们大概花了六到八个月的时间在用户引导(onboarding)上做了不少投入，包括那个向导功能、The Mole持续教育模块，还有一些个性化的东西，这些加起来让Airtable的激活率(activation rate)提升了20%。
text_es: Llevábamos varios años trabajando en la activación antes de que yo llegara a Airtable. Ya teníamos un equipo de activación increíble, trabajando a full. En general, las inversiones que hicimos en onboarding durante unos seis a ocho meses - que incluían el asistente (wizard), The Mole con educación continua, y también algo de personalización - todo eso junto nos dio un aumento del 20% en la tasa de activación de Airtable.
context: Lenny asks about the impact of Lauryn's onboarding optimization work at Airtable. Lauryn explains that her team built several components including a guided onboarding wizard, an ongoing education feature they called 'The Mole', and personalization features. She shares that these combined efforts resulted in a significant 20% improvement in their activation rate over a 6-8 month period.
vocabulary_highlights: hard at work, drove a 20% lift

speaker: Lauryn Isford
text: I think it speaks to the importance of really understanding what a user needs to be onboarded well, which is not the same as what your business wants the user to be onboarded to. So, delineating those and building carefully is really what made it successful.
text_ko: 제 생각에는 사용자를 제대로 온보딩(onboarding)하려면 사용자가 진짜로 필요한 게 뭔지를 확실히 이해하는 게 중요해요. 그건 회사가 사용자를 온보딩하길 원하는 방향과는 같지 않거든요. 그래서 둘을 명확히 구분하고 신중하게 설계·구축한 게 성공의 비결이었어요.
text_zh: 我觉得这说明了一个道理，就是你得真正搞清楚用户需要什么样的引导体验，这跟你的业务希望用户接受什么样的引导是两码事。所以呢，把这两者区分开来，然后仔细打磨产品，这才是成功的关键。
text_es: Creo que esto demuestra lo importante que es entender realmente lo que un usuario necesita para hacer bien su onboarding, que no es lo mismo que lo que tu empresa quiere que el usuario aprenda en el onboarding. Entonces, separar esas dos cosas y construir cuidadosamente es lo que realmente lo hizo exitoso.
context: Lauryn continues discussing the success of Airtable's onboarding improvements. She emphasizes a key insight from their work - there's often a mismatch between what users actually need during onboarding versus what the business wants to show them. She credits their success to carefully distinguishing between these two perspectives and prioritizing user needs in their onboarding design.
vocabulary_highlights: delineating those, building carefully

speaker: Lauryn Isford
text: I think one other big learning for us was that we had to meet users where they are. We have some awesome advanced features of really cool stuff you can do with Airtable, automations being a great example. However, users don't necessarily need to get that started on day one. They don't need to learn about the advanced stuff when they haven't even looked at a workflow before.
text_ko: 저희가 또 배운 큰 교훈 중 하나는 사용자들이 있는 곳에서 만나야 한다는 거예요. 에어테이블(Airtable)로 할 수 있는 정말 멋진 고급 기능들이 많은데, 자동화(automations)가 대표적인 예예요. 하지만 사용자들이 첫날부터 그걸 바로 시작할 필요는 없어요. 워크플로(workflow)를 아직 한 번도 안 봤는데 고급 기능을 배우게 할 필요는 없어요.
text_zh: 我觉得我们还有一个很大的收获就是，你得从用户的实际情况出发。我们Airtable有很多很牛的高级功能，比如自动化(automations)这些特别酷的东西。但是用户第一天上手的时候，其实根本不需要这些。他们连基本的工作流程(workflow)都还没搞明白呢，你让他们学这些高级功能干嘛。
text_es: Creo que otro gran aprendizaje para nosotros fue que teníamos que encontrar a los usuarios donde están. Tenemos funcionalidades avanzadas súper geniales, cosas increíbles que puedes hacer con Airtable, las automatizaciones son un ejemplo perfecto. Sin embargo, los usuarios no necesariamente necesitan saber todo eso desde el primer día. No necesitan aprender sobre las funciones avanzadas cuando ni siquiera han visto un flujo de trabajo (workflow) antes.
context: Lenny asks about general learnings from optimizing onboarding experiences. Lauryn shares a key insight about avoiding the temptation to showcase advanced features too early in the user journey. Using Airtable's automations feature as an example, she explains that users who haven't even explored basic workflows don't need to learn about advanced functionality on day one - you have to meet users at their current skill level.
vocabulary_highlights: meet users where they are, get that started on day one, haven't even looked at a workflow before

speaker: Lauryn Isford
text: In general, I think an activation rate that falls in a lower percentage range, maybe for most companies five to 15%, is better than one that falls in a higher percentage range because it means that there's likely much higher correlation with long-term retention and you're really working hard to get most of your users to reach a state that they're not reaching today.
text_ko: 전반적으로 활성화율(activation rate)이 낮은, 대부분의 회사는 대략 5~15% 정도인 수치가 높은 편보다 낫다고 봐요. 그게 장기 리텐션(long-term retention)과 더 높은 상관관계를 가질 가능성이 크고, 지금 대부분의 사용자가 아직 도달하지 못한 상태로 대다수 사용자를 끌어올리기 위해 정말 열심히 노력하고 있다는 뜻이거든요.
text_zh: 一般来说，我觉得激活率(activation rate)保持在比较低的百分比范围内会更好，对大多数公司来说可能是5%到15%，这比那些高百分比的激活率要好，因为这说明跟长期留存的关联度(correlation)会高很多，而且你真的在下功夫让大部分用户达到他们现在还没达到的状态。
text_es: En general, creo que una tasa de activación que esté en un rango más bajo, digamos entre el cinco y quince por ciento para la mayoría de empresas, es mejor que una que esté en un rango más alto, porque significa que probablemente hay una correlación mucho mayor con la retención a largo plazo y realmente estás trabajando duro para lograr que la mayoría de tus usuarios lleguen a un estado al que no están llegando hoy en día.
context: Lenny asks about Lauryn's perspective on choosing activation metrics, specifically her belief that lower activation rates can be better than higher ones. Lauryn explains her counterintuitive heuristic that an activation metric with a 5-15% rate is often superior to one with a higher percentage. Her reasoning is that lower rates typically indicate stronger correlation with long-term retention because you're setting a high bar that requires meaningful user behavior rather than easy-to-achieve actions.
vocabulary_highlights: falls in a lower percentage range, much higher correlation with long-term retention, reach a state that they're not reaching today

speaker: Logan Kilpatrick
text: I think finding people who are high agency and work with urgency, if I was hiring five people today, those are some of the top two characteristics that I would look for in people because you can take on the world if you have people who have high agency and not needing to get 50 people's different consensus. They hear something from our customers about a challenge that they're having, and they're already pushing on what the solution for them is and not waiting for all the other things to happen that... People just go and do it and solve the problem, and I love that.
