text_ko: 저는 높은 주도성(high agency)과 긴급함(urgency)을 갖고 일하는 사람들을 찾는 게 중요하다고 생각해요. 만약 오늘 다섯 명을 뽑는다면 그 두 가지가 가장 먼저 보는 특성일 거예요. 그런 사람들만 있으면 못할 일이 없거든요—50명씩 여기저기 합의를 구할 필요가 없어요. 고객이 어떤 문제를 말하면 이미 해결책을 고민하고 어떻게 해결할지 밀어붙이기 시작하고, 다른 일들이 다 갖춰지길 기다리지 않아요. 그냥 가서 문제를 해결해 버리는 사람들인데, 저는 그런 태도를 정말 좋아해요.
text_zh: 我觉得找那种特别有主动性、做事急迫感很强的人，如果我今天要招五个人的话，这两个特质绝对是我最看重的。因为有了这样的人，你就能闯出一片天地，不用去搞什么50个人的共识那一套。他们一听到客户反映什么问题，马上就开始琢磨解决方案了，不会等这等那的...就是那种直接上手解决问题的人，我特别喜欢这样的。
text_es: Si hoy tuviera que contratar a cinco personas, creo que buscaría gente que tome la iniciativa y que trabaje con urgencia - esas serían las dos características principales que buscaría. Porque puedes conquistar el mundo si tienes gente que tiene alta autonomía (high agency) y que no necesita el consenso de 50 personas diferentes. Escuchan algo de nuestros clientes sobre algún problema que tienen, y ya están trabajando en cuál va a ser la solución para ellos, sin esperar a que pasen todas las otras cosas que... La gente simplemente va y lo hace, resuelve el problema, y eso me encanta.
context: Lenny asks Logan about what makes OpenAI able to ship products so quickly compared to his previous companies like Apple and NASA. Logan explains that the two most important characteristics they look for when hiring are high agency and urgency. High agency means employees can make decisions independently without needing consensus from many people, while urgency means they act quickly when they identify problems or opportunities.
vocabulary_highlights: high agency, pushing on, take on the world

speaker: Logan Kilpatrick
text: I think where you start to get into some of these very vertical applications... And I think a great example of this is actually Harvey. I don't know if you've seen Harvey, but it's this legal AI use case where they're building custom models and tools to help lawyers and people at legal firms and stuff like that. And that's a great example of our models are probably never going to be as capable as some of the things that Harvey's doing because our goal and our mission is really to solve this very general use case and then people can do things like fine-tuning and build all their own custom UI and product features on top of that.
text_ko: 이런 특정 분야의 애플리케이션에 대해 이야기할 때, 좋은 예시가 바로 Harvey예요. 혹시 Harvey를 들어본 적이 있나요? 이건 법률 AI의 사례로, 변호사와 법률 사무소에서 일하는 사람들을 돕기 위해 맞춤형 모델과 도구를 만들고 있어요. 우리 모델이 Harvey가 하는 것만큼 능력이 뛰어나지는 않을 것 같아요. 왜냐하면 우리의 목표와 미션은 아주 일반적인 사용 사례를 해결하는 것이고, 그 위에 사람들이 자신만의 UI나 제품 기능을 추가할 수 있도록 하는 거니까요.
text_zh: 我觉得当你开始进入一些非常垂直的应用场景时...我觉得Harvey就是一个很好的例子。不知道你有没有听说过Harvey，它是一个法律AI应用案例，专门为律师和律所的人员构建定制化模型和工具。这就是一个很好的例子——我们的模型可能永远不会像Harvey做的那些东西那么强大，因为我们的目标和使命实际上是解决非常通用的使用场景，然后大家可以在此基础上进行微调(fine-tuning)，构建自己的定制UI和产品功能。
text_es: Creo que cuando empezás a meterte en estas aplicaciones súper específicas... Y un ejemplo buenísimo de esto es Harvey. No sé si lo conocés, pero es un caso de uso de IA legal donde están construyendo modelos y herramientas a medida para ayudar a abogados y gente de bufetes jurídicos y todo eso. Y ese es un gran ejemplo de que nuestros modelos probablemente nunca van a ser tan capaces como algunas de las cosas que está haciendo Harvey porque nuestro objetivo y nuestra misión realmente es resolver este caso de uso súper general, y después la gente puede hacer cosas como fine-tuning y construir toda su propia interfaz personalizada y funcionalidades de producto encima de eso.
context: Lenny asks Logan how developers should think about building products that won't be disrupted by OpenAI in the future. Logan explains that OpenAI focuses on general reasoning capabilities rather than specific vertical applications. He uses Harvey, a legal AI company, as an example of how companies can build specialized tools for specific industries that OpenAI won't compete with directly.
vocabulary_highlights: vertical applications, fine-tuning
topics: Product Management, Strategy & Planning, Starting a Company

speaker: Logan Kilpatrick
text: My whole position on this is prompt engineering is a very human thing. When we want to get some value out of a human, we do this prompt engineering. We try to effectively communicate with that human in order to get the best output. And the same thing is true of models. And I think it's like, again, because we're using a system that appears to be really smart, we assume that it has all this context, but it's really like imagine a human level intelligence but literally no context.
text_ko: 제 입장은 이거예요. 프롬프트 엔지니어링(prompt engineering)은 아주 인간적인 일이에요. 사람에게서 뭔가 가치를 얻으려면 하듯이, 최상의 결과를 얻으려고 그 사람과 효과적으로 소통하려고 노력하잖아요. 모델도 똑같아요. 그리고 우리가 똑똑해 보이는 시스템을 쓰다 보니 그 시스템이 모든 맥락을 알고 있다고 가정하기 쉬운데, 사실 인간 수준의 지능이 있다고 해도 맥락이 전혀 없는 사람을 상상하면 돼요.
text_zh: 我对这个事情的看法是，提示工程(prompt engineering)其实是很人性化的东西。你想想，我们要从一个人身上得到价值的时候，不也是在做提示工程嘛。我们会想办法跟那个人有效沟通，这样才能得到最好的结果。对模型也是一样的道理。我觉得就是因为我们用的这个系统看起来特别聪明，我们就以为它什么背景信息都知道，但实际上你可以把它想象成一个智商很高的人，但是完全没有任何背景信息。
text_es: Mi posición sobre esto es que la ingeniería de prompts (prompt engineering) es algo muy humano. Cuando queremos sacar valor de una persona, hacemos esto mismo - ingeniería de prompts. Tratamos de comunicarnos de manera efectiva con esa persona para obtener el mejor resultado. Y exactamente lo mismo pasa con los modelos. Y creo que es como... otra vez, como estamos usando un sistema que parece súper inteligente, asumimos que tiene todo este contexto, pero en realidad es como imaginarte una inteligencia a nivel humano pero literalmente sin contexto alguno.
context: Lenny asks Logan to explain prompt engineering and give advice on writing better prompts for ChatGPT. Logan explains that prompt engineering exists because AI models, like humans, need context to give good responses. He draws an analogy between communicating effectively with humans and communicating with AI models - both require providing sufficient context to get valuable output.
vocabulary_highlights: human level intelligence

speaker: Logan Kilpatrick
text: Context is the only thing that matters. It's such an important piece of getting a language model to do anything for you.
text_ko: 문맥(context)이 전부예요. 언어 모델(language model)에게 뭔가 시키려면 그 문맥이 정말 중요해요.
text_zh: 上下文是唯一重要的东西。想让语言模型(language model)帮你做任何事，这一点太关键了。
text_es: El contexto es lo único que realmente importa. Es clave para lograr que un modelo de lenguaje te funcione como necesitas.
context: Logan continues explaining prompt engineering best practices to Lenny. He emphasizes that the most critical factor in getting good results from AI models is providing adequate context. Logan suggests that if OpenAI made t-shirts, they should say 'Context is all you need' because context is so fundamental to effective AI interaction.

speaker: Logan Kilpatrick
text: I think the thing that surprised me the most was just how quickly everybody got back to business. I flew to San Francisco the next week after Thanksgiving, which I wasn't planning to do, to deal with the team in person and seeing, literally Monday morning, I was walking into the office being, like expecting, I don't know, something weird to be going on or happening. And really it was like people laser focused and back to work, and I think that speaks to the caliber of our team and everybody who's just so excited about building towards the mission that we're building towards.
text_ko: 가장 놀랐던 건 다들 얼마나 빨리 바로 업무 모드로 돌아왔는가였어요. 원래 계획엔 없었는데 추수감사절 다음 주에 샌프란시스코로 가서 팀을 직접 만나고 왔어요. 월요일 아침 사무실에 들어서면서 혹시 뭔가 이상한 일이 벌어지고 있지 않을까 기대했는데, 막상 가보니 다들 완전히 집중해서 일하고 있더라고요. 그 모습을 보면서 우리 팀의 수준을 느꼈고, 우리가 이루려는 미션을 향해 함께 일하는 데 다들 얼마나 신나하고 열정적인지도 알겠더라고요.
text_zh: 我觉得最让我意外的是，大家这么快就重新投入工作了。感恩节后那周我临时飞到旧金山，本来没打算去的，就是为了跟团队当面聊聊。结果周一早上我走进办公室的时候，还以为会有什么奇怪的氛围或者别的什么情况。没想到大家都特别专注，该干嘛干嘛，这真的说明了我们团队的水平，每个人都对我们要实现的目标特别有激情。
text_es: Lo que más me sorprendió fue lo rápido que todos regresaron al trabajo. Volé a San Francisco la semana después del Día de Acción de Gracias, algo que no tenía planeado hacer, para estar con el equipo en persona. Y cuando llegué literalmente el lunes por la mañana, iba caminando hacia la oficina esperando no sé, que hubiera algo raro pasando. Pero en realidad fue como ver a la gente súper enfocada y de vuelta al trabajo, y creo que eso habla de la calidad de nuestro equipo y de todos los que están súper emocionados por construir hacia la misión que estamos construyendo.
context: Lenny asks Logan about the dramatic weekend when OpenAI's board fired and then rehired CEO Sam Altman. Logan describes how the incident occurred during what was supposed to be the company's first major break since ChatGPT launched. He explains that what surprised him most was how quickly the team refocused on work after the crisis, demonstrating their commitment to OpenAI's mission.
vocabulary_highlights: laser focused, caliber of our team, building towards the mission

speaker: Logan Kilpatrick
text: I think 2024 is the year of multimodal AI, but it's also the year that people really push the boundaries of some of these new UX paradigms around AI.
text_ko: 제 생각에는 2024년이 멀티모달 AI(multimodal AI)의 해인 것 같아요. 동시에 사람들이 이 새로운 AI 관련 UX 패러다임(UX paradigms)들 중 일부의 경계를 정말로 밀어붙이는 해이기도 해요.
text_zh: 我觉得2024年是多模态AI(multimodal AI)的元年，但同时也是大家真正开始突破AI用户体验(UX)新范式边界的一年。
text_es: Creo que el 2024 va a ser el año de la IA multimodal, pero también va a ser cuando la gente realmente se lance a explorar los límites de estos nuevos paradigmas de experiencia de usuario (UX paradigms) en torno a la IA.
context: Lenny asks Logan about the most mind-blowing AI applications he's seen recently. Logan discusses new interfaces for AI interaction beyond traditional chatbots, mentioning products like the Rabbit R-1 and TL Draw. He explains that while chat is currently the dominant way people use AI, he's excited about new user experience paradigms that move beyond simple text-based interactions.
vocabulary_highlights: multimodal AI, push the boundaries, UX paradigms

speaker: Logan Kilpatrick
text: I've got it. It's on a Post-It note that I... Right behind my camera and it's 'Measure in hundreds.' I love this idea of measuring things in hundreds, and it's for folks who are at the beginning of some journey. I talk to people all the time, they're like, 'Yeah, I've tried this thing and it hasn't worked.' And if your mental model is to measure in hundreds, 'I measure in hundreds,' the five times that you failed at something, you failed and tried zero times.
text_ko: 있어요. 제 카메라 바로 뒤에 붙여둔 포스트잇에 적어 놨죠. '수백 단위로 측정하라(measure in hundreds)'. 저는 이 수백 단위로 측정하라는 생각이 정말 마음에 들고, 어떤 여정을 막 시작한 사람들에게 특히 맞는 말이라고 생각해요. 사람들 만나면 늘 '해봤는데 안 됐어요'라고들 해요. 그런데 당신의 멘탈 모델(mental model)이 '수백 단위로 측정한다'라면, 다섯 번 실패했다고 하는 건 사실상 실패가 아니라 시도한 걸로도 안 치는 거예요.
text_zh: 我明白了。我在一张便利贴(Post-It note)上写了这个，就贴在我摄像头后面，上面写着"以百为单位来衡量"。我特别喜欢这个概念，就是用一百次来衡量事情，这主要是给那些刚开始某个journey的人的建议。我经常遇到有人跟我说："哎，我试过这个东西，但是没成功。"但如果你的思维模式是"以百为单位来衡量"，那么你失败的那五次，其实等于零次，你还没开始呢。
text_es: Ya lo tengo. Está en un Post-It que tengo... justo detrás de mi cámara y dice 'Mide en cientos.' Me encanta esta idea de medir las cosas en cientos, y es para la gente que está empezando algún proyecto. Hablo con personas todo el tiempo que me dicen, 'Sí, probé esto y no funcionó.' Y si tu modelo mental es medir en cientos, 'Yo mido en cientos,' esas cinco veces que fallaste en algo, fallaste y probaste cero veces.
context: Lenny asks Logan about his favorite life motto during the lightning round. Logan shares his personal motto 'Measure in hundreds' which he keeps on a Post-It note behind his camera. He explains this philosophy helps people understand that success requires many attempts - if you think in terms of hundreds of tries, then failing five times means you've barely started, not that you should give up.
vocabulary_highlights: mental model, measure in hundreds

speaker: Luc Levesque
text: We talk about the 10X engineer and we don't really talk about the 10X growth advisor or 10X growth person, but the same dynamic applies. You could argue it applies even more because the right growth advisor can have literally company changing impact. Something I've experienced several times in hindsight when you're like, "Okay, here's the needle in the haystack." And then it's implemented and you can see hundreds of percentages, sometimes over a thousand percent lift when you get it right.
text_ko: 우리는 10배 엔지니어(10X engineer)에 대해서는 자주 얘기하지만, 10배 그로스 어드바이저(10X growth advisor)나 10배 그로스 담당자(10X growth person)에 대해서는 별로 얘기하지 않아요. 그런데 같은 역학이 적용돼요. 오히려 더 크게 적용된다고 주장할 수도 있는데, 적절한 그로스 어드바이저가 말 그대로 회사를 바꿔놓을 수 있기 때문이에요. 제가 뒤돌아보면 몇 번이나 경험한 건데, '아, 이게 건초 더미 속의 바늘이구나' 싶은 순간이 있어요. 그걸 실행하면 수백 퍼센트, 때로는 천 퍼센트가 넘는 증가(lift)를 보기도 해요.
text_zh: 我们总是在说10X工程师(10X engineer)，但很少提到10X增长顾问(10X growth advisor)或者10X增长专家(10X growth person)，其实道理是一样的。你甚至可以说增长顾问的影响更大，因为一个靠谱的增长顾问真的能彻底改变一家公司。我自己就经历过好几次，回头看的时候就觉得"哎呀，这就是大海捞针找到的宝贝啊"。一旦落地执行，效果立竿见影，提升几百个百分点，有时候甚至能达到一千多个百分点，只要你找对了人。
text_es: Hablamos del ingeniero 10X y realmente no hablamos del asesor de crecimiento 10X o la persona de crecimiento 10X, pero la misma dinámica se aplica. Podrías argumentar que se aplica incluso más porque el asesor de crecimiento correcto puede tener literalmente un impacto que cambie la empresa. Es algo que he experimentado varias veces y que en retrospectiva dices, "Okay, aquí está la aguja en el pajar." Y luego se implementa y puedes ver mejoras de cientos de porcentajes, a veces más del mil por ciento cuando lo haces bien.
context: Lenny asks Luc about the value and impact of growth advisors compared to other types of advisors or hires. Luc explains that while people often discuss the concept of "10X engineers" - exceptional engineers who provide vastly outsized value - the same principle applies even more strongly to growth advisors. He argues that finding the right growth advisor can literally change a company's trajectory, sometimes delivering hundreds or even thousands of percent improvements when the right strategy is implemented.
vocabulary_highlights: needle in the haystack, literally company changing impact, hundreds of percentages, over a thousand percent lift

speaker: Luc Levesque
text: It's one of those weird disciplines where the right person at the right time can literally say a sentence that changes the trajectory of your company. You can't say that for a lot of different disciplines, but this is one of them.
text_ko: 이건 좀 특이한 분야예요. 딱 맞는 사람이 딱 맞는 타이밍에 한 문장만 해도 회사의 방향을 완전히 바꿔놓을 수 있어요. 다른 많은 분야들에 대해선 그렇게 말하기 어렵지만, 이건 그런 경우예요.
text_zh: 这就是那种很奇妙的领域，合适的人在合适的时机说一句话，真的能改变你公司的发展轨迹。很多其他领域都做不到这一点，但这个领域就是有这种魔力。
text_es: Es una de esas disciplinas raras donde la persona indicada en el momento preciso puede literalmente decir una frase que te cambia completamente el rumbo de la empresa. No puedes decir eso de muchas otras disciplinas, pero esta sí es una de ellas.
context: Luc continues explaining why growth advisors can be so valuable to companies. He emphasizes that growth is unique among business disciplines because a single insight or recommendation from an experienced growth expert can fundamentally alter a company's path. This is different from other areas where impact typically requires sustained effort over time - in growth, one conversation or piece of advice can unlock massive improvements.
vocabulary_highlights: weird disciplines, changes the trajectory

speaker: Luc Levesque
text: I think what it highlights is something that Facebook does really, really well, which you get very quickly when you join Facebook and it's why they're such an execution machine and can build a lot of great product. It's because they focus exclusively on that magic word, which is impact.
text_ko: 제 생각에 이 말이 보여주는 건 페이스북이 정말 잘하는 한 가지예요. 페이스북에 들어가면 금방 느낄 수 있고, 그게 바로 그들이 실행력이 뛰어나 많은 훌륭한 제품을 만들 수 있는 이유예요. 이유는 딱 한 단어, 바로 임팩트(impact)에만 집중하기 때문이에요.
text_zh: 我觉得这说明了Facebook真正厉害的地方，你一进Facebook就能很快感受到，这也是为什么他们执行力这么强，能做出这么多好产品。因为他们就专注一个关键词——影响力(impact)。
text_es: Creo que lo que resalta es algo que Facebook hace increíblemente bien, algo que captas muy rápido cuando entras a trabajar en Facebook y es la razón por la que son una máquina de ejecución tremenda y pueden crear productos buenísimos. Es porque se enfocan exclusivamente en esa palabra mágica, que es el impacto.
context: Luc is sharing a story about his first major review at Facebook with Mark Zuckerberg, where he was asked directly about when they would see results from his strategy. He explains that this experience taught him about Facebook's core cultural value of focusing on impact rather than activities or effort. This laser focus on measurable outcomes is what makes Facebook an "execution machine" capable of building great products consistently.
vocabulary_highlights: execution machine, magic word, focus exclusively

speaker: Luc Levesque
text: The second one, which I had I suppose never experienced before, was that they made it very personal. I had these reasons why I couldn't leave. So initially I was excited by the opportunity, but I couldn't see myself moving to California for personal reasons. And through discussions, Mark basically involved my wife, involved my spouse in this, Andrea.
text_ko: 두 번째로는, 제가 이전에 겪어본 적 없는 건데 그들이 접근을 아주 개인적으로 했어요. 저는 떠날 수 없는 개인적인 이유들이 있었거든요. 그래서 처음에는 그 기회가 흥미로웠지만 개인적인 사정 때문에 캘리포니아로 이사할 거라고는 상상이 잘 안 됐어요. 논의하는 과정에서 마크가 사실상 제 아내 안드레아까지 이 일에 끌어들였어요.
text_zh: 第二点，我之前从来没遇到过这种情况，就是他们把这事儿搞得特别个人化。我当时有一些个人原因没法离开现在的地方。一开始我对这个机会挺兴奋的，但是因为个人原因，我真的没法想象自己搬到加州去。后来聊着聊着，Mark基本上把我老婆也拉进来了，就是我的爱人Andrea。
text_es: La segunda cosa, que supongo nunca había vivido antes, fue que lo hicieron muy personal. Yo tenía mis razones por las que no podía irme. Entonces al principio me emocionó la oportunidad, pero no me veía mudándome a California por temas personales. Y a través de las conversaciones, Mark básicamente involucró a mi esposa en esto, involucró a mi pareja, Andrea.
context: Lenny asks Luc about being personally recruited by Mark Zuckerberg to join Facebook. Luc is sharing the key lessons he learned from that recruitment process about how to effectively hire top talent. He explains that one crucial strategy was making the recruitment process personal by involving family members, recognizing that career decisions affect entire families, not just the individual being hired.
vocabulary_highlights: made it very personal, couldn't see myself

speaker: Luc Levesque
text: Another great sign of excellence, and this was just through reflecting on stars on the team and thinking what makes them unique, what about them. One of them is when somebody's boss leaves the company and then comes back to poach them, that is such a strong signal because if you think of what just happened, the leader who knows exactly how good this person you're talking to is, they have the most knowledge of the performance of this individual, they left the company.
text_ko: 탁월함을 알려주는 또 하나의 확실한 신호가 있어요. 팀의 스타들을 떠올리며 그들이 무엇이 특별한지 생각해봤는데, 그중 하나는 상사가 회사를 떠났다가 다시 돌아와 그 직원을 데려가려 할 때예요. 이건 정말 강력한 신호예요. 왜냐하면 그 사람의 실력을 제일 잘 아는 리더가 직접 움직였다는 뜻이니까요.
text_zh: 还有一个卓越员工的重要标志，这是我通过观察团队里的明星员工，思考他们的独特之处得出的。就是当某人的老板离开公司后，又回来挖他们，这绝对是个超强信号。你想想啊，这个领导最了解这个人到底有多厉害，对他的表现最有发言权，结果离职后还专门回来poach（挖角）他。
text_es: Otra señal buenísima de excelencia, y esto me di cuenta simplemente reflexionando sobre las estrellas del equipo y pensando qué los hace únicos. Una de esas señales es cuando el jefe de alguien se va de la empresa y después regresa para llevárselo, eso es una señal súper fuerte porque si te pones a pensar en lo que acaba de pasar: el líder que sabe exactamente qué tan bueno es esta persona de la que estás hablando, el que más conoce el desempeño de esta persona, se fue de la empresa.
context: Lenny asks Luc about his hiring playbook and what he looks for when evaluating talent. Luc is explaining his concept of "signs of excellence" - indicators that someone has repeatedly demonstrated exceptional performance. He describes one particularly strong signal: when a former manager leaves a company and then returns specifically to recruit that person to their new company, which demonstrates the manager's confidence in that person's abilities.
vocabulary_highlights: sign of excellence, comes back to poach them, such a strong signal

speaker: Luc Levesque
text: Growth advice is generally always applicable. And if you can start thinking about how to build your product early, even if it's pre-product market fit, you're not going to do any damage, but you may be wasting some capital on an advisor or a growth person too early. The problem that I see is if you start growing a product that doesn't have product market fit, you're actually doing more damage than good because you have a product that is now being exposed to the market through growth levers and through optimization that is giving a bad experience with your product.
text_ko: 그로스 조언(growth advice)은 보통 거의 항상 적용돼요. 그리고 설령 제품-시장 적합성 전(pre-product-market fit)이라도 초기에 제품을 어떻게 만들지 생각하기 시작하는 건 해가 되지 않아요. 다만 어드바이저(advisor)나 그로스 담당자(growth person)를 너무 일찍 데려오면 자본을 낭비할 수는 있어요. 제가 보는 문제는 제품-시장 적합성(product-market fit)이 없는 상태에서 제품을 성장시키기 시작하면 오히려 해가 된다는 점이에요. 그 제품이 그로스 레버(growth levers)나 최적화(optimization)를 통해 시장에 노출되면 사용자에게 안 좋은 경험을 주게 되거든요.
text_zh: 关于增长的建议其实什么时候都用得上。如果你能早点开始考虑怎么打造产品，哪怕还没找到产品市场契合度(product market fit)，也不会有什么坏处，顶多就是太早请增长顾问或者招增长的人，多花点钱而已。但我看到的问题是，如果你开始推广一个还没找到产品市场契合度的产品，那反而是弊大于利。因为你的产品现在通过各种增长手段和优化被推到市场上，给用户的体验很糟糕。
text_es: Los consejos de crecimiento normalmente siempre sirven. Y si puedes empezar a pensar en cómo hacer crecer tu producto desde temprano, aunque todavía no tengas product market fit, no vas a hacer ningún daño, pero tal vez estés malgastando algo de capital en un asesor o en alguien de growth demasiado pronto. El problema que veo es que si empiezas a hacer crecer un producto que no tiene product market fit, en realidad estás haciendo más daño que bien porque tienes un producto que ahora se está exponiendo al mercado a través de palancas de crecimiento (growth levers) y optimización que está dando una mala experiencia con tu producto.
context: Lenny asks Luc to explain why founders should wait until they have product-market fit before focusing on growth, since this advice comes up frequently. Luc explains that while growth advice itself isn't harmful early on, actively growing a product that doesn't satisfy user needs can be damaging. When you use growth tactics to expose more people to a product that provides a poor experience, you're essentially burning through potential customers who are unlikely to return and try your product again later.
vocabulary_highlights: wasting some capital, growth levers, giving a bad experience

speaker: Luc Levesque
text: I mean, one example would be a company that I worked with. Now, a public company. At the time, they weren't. On day one, walked in, they presented their strategy, their plans, their funnels and their landing pages. I could see very quickly that there was something they were doing that was a little off and I asked them, "Well, why are you doing it that way?" And they said, "Well, we think it just looks better that way." And I said, "Well, just do it this other way." I remember this because it was such a short conversation and then three weeks later we connected and I heard they had rolled it out and it was a large impact that they had from this one change.
text_ko: 예를 들면, 제가 함께 일했던 회사 하나가 있어요. 지금은 상장사(public company)이에요. 그때는 아니었죠. 첫날 들어가서 그들의 전략, 계획, 퍼널(funnel)과 랜딩 페이지(landing page)를 보여주더라고요. 금방 뭔가 좀 이상하다는 게 보이길래 "왜 그렇게 하고 계세요?"라고 물어봤더니, "그게 더 보기 좋아서요"라고 하더라고요. 그래서 제가 "그럼 이렇게 해 보세요"라고 했어요. 대화가 워낙 짧았던 게 기억에 남는데, 3주쯤 뒤에 연락이 닿아서 들어보니 그걸 적용했고, 그 한 번의 변경으로 큰 효과를 봤다고 하더라고요.
text_zh: 我记得有一个例子，是我合作过的一家公司。现在已经上市了，但当时还没有。第一天进去的时候，他们给我展示了他们的策略、计划、还有漏斗(funnel)和着陆页(landing page)。我很快就看出来他们有个地方做得不太对，就问他们："你们为什么要这么做？"他们说："我们觉得这样看起来更好看。"我就说："那你们试试用另一种方法。"我记得特别清楚，因为当时聊得很简单，结果三周后我们再联系的时候，听说他们已经上线了，就这一个改动带来的效果特别大。
text_es: Te doy un ejemplo de una empresa con la que trabajé. Ahora es una empresa que cotiza en bolsa, pero en ese momento no. El primer día que llegué, me presentaron su estrategia, sus planes, sus embudos (funnels) y sus páginas de aterrizaje (landing pages). Me di cuenta muy rápido de que había algo que estaban haciendo medio raro y les pregunté: "Oye, ¿por qué lo están haciendo así?" Y me dijeron: "Pues es que creemos que se ve mejor de esta manera." Y yo les dije: "Mira, mejor háganlo de esta otra forma." Me acuerdo porque fue una conversación súper corta, y tres semanas después nos conectamos y me dijeron que ya lo habían implementado y que ese cambio les había dado un impacto enorme.
context: Lenny asks for an example of the kind of massive impact that a growth advisor can have in a short time. Luc shares a story about advising a company (now public) where he identified an issue with their approach on his first day. Through his experience, he could quickly spot something that seemed off about their strategy. After a brief conversation and simple recommendation, the company implemented his suggestion and saw significant results within three weeks, demonstrating how years of expertise can be distilled into moments of high-impact advice.
vocabulary_highlights: rolled it out, large impact, such a short conversation

speaker: Lulu Cheng Meservey
text: I often say to find your audience's cultural erogenous zones. So what it means is people have things that they either care about or don't, and you're not going to change that. So it's a huge lift to try to change someone's worldview or their passions. It's a light lift to take the thing you want to talk about and just shape it into, to fit into their worldview or their passions.
text_ko: 저는 자주 청중의 문화적 민감 지점(cultural erogenous zones)을 찾아보라고 말해요. 그 말은 사람들이 어떤 것에는 관심을 갖고 어떤 것에는 관심이 없다는 뜻이고, 그걸 바꾸기는 쉽지 않다는 뜻이에요. 누군가의 세계관이나 열정을 바꾸려 들면 엄청난 노력이 필요하지만, 당신이 말하려는 내용을 그들의 세계관이나 열정에 맞게 조금만 다듬어 전달하는 건 훨씬 덜 힘들어요.
text_zh: 我经常说要找到你目标受众的文化敏感点。意思就是说，每个人都有自己在乎的和不在乎的东西，这你是改变不了的。你要想去改变别人的世界观或者他们的热情所在，那可太费劲了。但如果你把想说的内容稍微包装一下，让它符合他们的世界观和兴趣点，那就轻松多了。
text_es: Siempre digo que hay que encontrar los puntos sensibles culturales de tu audiencia. O sea, la gente tiene cosas que le importan mucho o que simplemente no le interesan, y eso no lo vas a cambiar. Es súper difícil tratar de cambiarle la mentalidad a alguien o sus pasiones. En cambio, es mucho más fácil tomar lo que tú quieres comunicar y simplemente adaptarlo para que encaje con su forma de ver las cosas o con lo que realmente les apasiona.
context: Lenny asks Lulu about what helps an idea spread effectively. Lulu introduces her framework of finding your audience's 'cultural erogenous zones' - the topics and values that naturally excite and engage specific groups of people. She explains that rather than trying to change people's existing passions or worldviews (which requires enormous effort), it's much more effective to adapt your message to align with what they already care deeply about.
vocabulary_highlights: cultural erogenous zones, huge lift, light lift, shape it into

speaker: Lulu Cheng Meservey
text: You have to make it memorable and you have to make people want to say it of their own volition. And so what doesn't make them want to say it is doing a favor for a corporation. What does make them want to say it is they want to bring joy to somebody else, they want to make somebody laugh, they want to appear interesting, or they want to project some part of their identity.
text_ko: 기억에 남게 만들어야 하고, 사람들이 스스로 말하고 싶게 만들어야 해요. 사람들이 스스로 말하고 싶지 않게 만드는 건 그게 단지 회사를 위해 호의를 베푸는 것처럼 느껴질 때예요. 반대로 사람들이 말하게 만드는 건 다른 사람에게 기쁨을 주고 싶거나, 누군가를 웃게 하고 싶거나, 자신을 흥미롭게 보이고 싶거나, 자신의 정체성 일부를 드러내고 싶을 때예요.
text_zh: 你得让内容有记忆点，还要让大家主动愿意去传播。如果只是在帮企业做宣传，那肯定没人愿意分享。但如果能让他们给别人带来快乐，或者逗别人一笑，又或者显得自己很有趣，能展现自己的个性，那他们就特别愿意去说了。
text_es: Tiene que ser algo memorable y tiene que lograr que la gente quiera compartirlo por sí misma. Y lo que NO los motiva a compartir es hacer un favor a una empresa. Lo que SÍ los motiva es querer alegrarle el día a alguien más, querer hacer reír a alguien, querer parecer interesantes, o querer mostrar algo de su personalidad.
context: Lenny asks Lulu broadly what she's learned about what helps an idea spread. Lulu explains the fundamental principle that ideas spread when people are intrinsically motivated to repeat them, not when they feel like they're doing a favor for a company. She identifies the key motivations that drive people to share content: bringing joy to others, making people laugh, appearing interesting, or expressing their identity.
vocabulary_highlights: of their own volition, project some part of their identity

speaker: Lulu Cheng Meservey
text: I think if you're a startup your enemy is the status quo. And when you don't take risks, when you minimize risk by doing nothing, the best way to minimize risk is to do nothing. You're letting the status quo win. You're letting your greatest enemy and rival and threat to your business win by default, because you're not even going to try to compete.
text_ko: 제 생각에는 스타트업(startup)의 가장 큰 적은 현상 유지(status quo)예요. 위험을 감수하지 않고 아무것도 하지 않으면서 리스크(risk)를 최소화하려고 할 때—사실 리스크를 가장 줄이는 방법이 아무것도 하지 않는 거죠. 그런데 그렇게 하면 결국 현상 유지가 이기는 거예요. 경쟁하려고조차 하지 않으니 당신의 가장 큰 적이자 라이벌이자 사업에 대한 위협을 자동으로 이겨 주는 셈이에요.
text_zh: 我觉得如果你是做创业的，那现状就是你最大的敌人。当你不愿意冒险，想通过什么都不做来降低风险的时候——确实，降低风险最保险的办法就是什么都不做——但这样你就是在让现状赢。你等于是让你最大的敌人、最大的竞争对手、对你生意威胁最大的东西不战而胜，因为你压根就没打算去拼一把。
text_es: Creo que si eres una startup, tu enemigo es el status quo. Y cuando no te arriesgas, cuando minimizas el riesgo no haciendo nada, que es la mejor manera de minimizar el riesgo, estás dejando que gane el status quo. Estás dejando que tu mayor enemigo, tu rival y la mayor amenaza para tu negocio gane por default, porque ni siquiera vas a intentar competir.
context: Lenny asks Lulu about her philosophy of taking risks as a communications person, noting that many comms professionals tend to be very conservative. Lulu explains why startups in particular must take risks in their communications strategy. She argues that for startups, avoiding risk by doing nothing actually allows their biggest competitor - the status quo - to win without any challenge.
vocabulary_highlights: win by default, try to compete

speaker: Lulu Cheng Meservey
text: If your natural audience cares about X and you're offering Y, then it's your job to create the API or to create the bridge from X to Y. With messaging, it's not build it and they will come. It is so hard and you'd have to be superhumanly gifted to the extent that I can't recall seeing in my entire life, where you create a message and a story so powerful that someone who didn't care at all before suddenly makes that their passion.
text_ko: 만약 원래 당신의 오디언스가 X에 관심 있고 당신이 Y를 제공한다면, X에서 Y로 이어주는 API(애플리케이션 프로그래밍 인터페이스)나 다리를 만드는 게 당신 역할이에요. 메시징(messaging)은 ‘만들어 놓으면 사람들이 올 거다’ 식으로 되는 게 아니에요. 그건 정말 힘들고, 제 평생을 통틀어도 본 기억이 없을 정도로 초인적인 재능이 있어야 가능한 일이에요 — 전혀 관심 없던 사람이 갑자기 그걸 자기의 열정으로 삼을 만큼 강력한 메시지와 스토리를 만들어내야 하니까요.
text_zh: 如果你的目标受众关心的是X，而你提供的是Y，那你就得想办法搭个桥，让X和Y连起来。做营销传播可不是"你建好了他们就会来"那么简单。想要创造一个强大到能让完全不感兴趣的人突然变得特别有激情的信息和故事，这难度太大了，你得有超人般的天赋才行——我这辈子都没见过谁能做到这一点。
text_es: Si a tu audiencia natural le importa X y tú estás ofreciendo Y, entonces tu trabajo es crear la API o crear el puente entre X e Y. Con el messaging, no es "constrúyelo y vendrán". Es súper difícil y tendrías que tener un talento sobrehumano - hasta el punto de que no recuerdo haber visto esto en toda mi vida - para crear un mensaje y una historia tan poderosos que alguien a quien no le importaba nada de repente lo convierta en su pasión.
context: Lenny asks Lulu to elaborate on her 'cultural erogenous zones' framework and wants examples of it in action. Lulu explains that when there's a mismatch between what your audience cares about and what you're offering, your job is to create connections between them. She emphasizes that the 'build it and they will come' approach rarely works in messaging - it's extremely difficult to create content so compelling that it changes someone's fundamental interests.
vocabulary_highlights: create the API, build it and they will come, superhumanly gifted

speaker: Lulu Cheng Meservey
text: First, you have to acknowledge that you're the underdog, and you're not going to use the GE playbook from the 1980s or whatever. So acknowledging that means knowing that you're not going to play the game that requires you to have more resources, more and deeper relationships, and institutional backings, and to be able to draft off of the current narrative.
text_ko: 먼저 우리가 언더독(underdog)이라는 걸 인정해야 해요. 그리고 1980년대 GE식 플레이북(GE playbook) 같은 방식을 그대로 쓸 수는 없다는 것도요. 그걸 인정한다는 건 더 많은 자원이나 더 넓고 깊은 인간관계, 기관의 지원이 있어야만 가능한 게임을 하지 않겠다는 뜻이에요. 지금 돌아가는 서사를 등에 업고 따라가거나 그 흐름을 그대로 따라가는 식으로는 이길 수 없다는 의미이기도 해요.
text_zh: 首先，你得承认自己是个小玩家，不能再用通用电气(GE)那套80年代的老路子了。承认这一点就意味着，你不能玩那种需要砸更多钱、拼更深人脉关系、靠大机构撑腰，还得跟着主流叙事走的游戏。
text_es: Primero, tienes que reconocer que eres el que va por detrás, y que no vas a usar el manual de GE de los años 80 ni nada parecido. Entonces, reconocer eso significa saber que no vas a jugar el juego donde necesitas tener más recursos, relaciones más profundas y amplias, respaldo institucional, y poder aprovecharte de la narrativa que ya está establecida.
context: Lenny asks what works best for underdog startups and companies trying to get attention against incumbent competitors. Lulu explains that underdog companies must first acknowledge their position and avoid trying to use the same strategies that work for established corporations with vast resources. She emphasizes that underdogs can't rely on having extensive resources, deep industry relationships, institutional support, or the ability to benefit from existing market narratives.
vocabulary_highlights: draft off of the current narrative, institutional backings

speaker: Lulu Cheng Meservey
text: So you take out your one-page Google Doc. I feel like most comms problems can be solved with one-page Google Doc. So you go to your one-page Google Doc and you take your audiences, you list them, probably stop at five or six because past that it's like way, way first world problem.
text_ko: 그럼 한 페이지짜리 구글 문서(one-page Google Doc)를 꺼내요. 제 생각엔 대부분의 커뮤니케이션 문제(comms)는 그 한 페이지로 해결할 수 있어요. 문서를 열고 대상(청중)을 쭉 적어 보세요. 보통 다섯, 여섯 개에서 멈추는 게 좋아요. 그 이상 가면 진짜 너무 사소한, 일종의 'first-world problem'이에요.
text_zh: 所以你就拿出你那个一页纸的Google文档。我觉得大部分沟通问题都能用一页纸的Google文档搞定。你打开你的一页纸Google文档，把你的目标受众列出来，大概列个五六个就够了，再多的话就有点矫情了。
text_es: Entonces sacas tu Google Doc de una página. Siento que la mayoría de los problemas de comunicación se pueden resolver con un Google Doc de una página. Vas a tu Google Doc de una página y pones tus audiencias, las enlistas, probablemente te detienes en cinco o seis porque más de eso ya es como un problema de primer mundo exagerado.
context: Lenny asks Lulu for practical advice on how someone should implement her concentric circles framework for spreading messages to different audience groups. Lulu provides a tactical approach, suggesting people create a simple one-page document to map out their target audiences. She emphasizes keeping it manageable by limiting to five or six audience groups, noting that having more audiences than that indicates the company has moved beyond early-stage challenges.
vocabulary_highlights: first world problem

speaker: Lulu Cheng Meservey
text: LinkedIn is super underutilized because it gets a ton of eyeballs in time, but most of the content sucks. 95% of the content this is not scientific - this is my might estimate. 95% of the content is people congratulating each other on work anniversaries or people saying, 'I'm so proud of my team for this thing they did.'
text_ko: 링크드인(LinkedIn)은 정말 과소활용되고 있어요. 장기적으로 보면 많은 사람들이 보는데, 정작 콘텐츠 대부분은 수준이 별로예요. 제 대략적인 추정으로는 약 95%가 과학적 근거가 없는 내용이고, 대부분 서로 근무 기념일을 축하하거나 “우리 팀이 이 성과를 냈어요, 정말 자랑스러워요” 같은 자랑글이에요.
text_zh: LinkedIn真的是被严重浪费了，因为它流量很大，用户花的时间也不少，但大部分内容都很水。我估计95%的内容——这不是科学统计啊，就是我的感觉——95%的内容都是互相祝贺工作周年纪念，或者发"我为我团队做的这件事感到骄傲"这种话。
text_es: LinkedIn está súper desaprovechado porque tiene un montón de usuarios y tiempo de pantalla, pero la mayoría del contenido es malísimo. El 95% del contenido - y esto no es científico, es mi estimación personal - el 95% del contenido es gente felicitándose por aniversarios laborales o diciendo "estoy tan orgulloso de mi equipo por esto que hicieron."
context: Lenny mentions that he gets more newsletter traffic from LinkedIn than Twitter and asks Lulu for her perspective on this platform choice. Lulu explains why LinkedIn represents an underutilized opportunity for professionals and founders. She argues that while LinkedIn receives significant user attention and engagement, the vast majority of content is low-quality social pleasantries rather than genuinely valuable information, creating an opportunity for those who post substantial content.
vocabulary_highlights: super underutilized, ton of eyeballs

speaker: Madhavan Ramanujam
text: The first one is you might land, but you might not expand. As in your eagerness for acquiring, you might have actually given away a lot at less and you have given the farm away, but you don't have anything to expand to. That's the first trap you're likely to fall into.
text_ko: 첫 번째 함정은 고객을 유치(land)는 할 수 있는데, 거기서 확장(expand)을 못하는 경우예요. 고객을 빨리 확보하려는 욕심 때문에 실제로 많은 걸 싸게 내주거나 거의 다 내줘버려서 확장할 기반이 남아있지 않을 수 있어요. 바로 그런 함정에 빠지기 쉬워요.
text_zh: 第一个坑就是，你可能拿下了客户，但是没办法做大。就是说你太急着想签单，可能给的条件太优惠了，把老本都赔进去了，但后面没有扩展的空间了。这是你最容易掉进去的第一个坑。
text_es: El primer error es que puedes conseguir el cliente, pero después no tienes margen para crecer. O sea, por las ganas que tenías de cerrar el trato, capaz que regalaste demasiado y terminaste vendiendo a precio de huevo, pero ahí te quedas - no tienes nada más que ofrecer. Esa es la primera trampa en la que te vas a meter.
context: Lenny asks Madhavan about common traps that founders fall into when building their companies. Madhavan is explaining the specific traps that 'disruptor archetype' companies face - those that focus heavily on customer acquisition and market share. He's describing how companies that are overly focused on landing new customers often make the mistake of offering too much value upfront at discounted prices, leaving nothing valuable to sell later for expansion revenue.
vocabulary_highlights: given the farm away, land, but you might not expand, eagerness for acquiring

speaker: Madhavan Ramanujam
text: The second trap that a moneymaker actually falls into is that you fall into the price premium paradox where you think that pricing high actually indicates value, but your price is so high that you actually start hurting your acquisition, so it just becomes irrelevant for most people.
text_ko: 돈을 잘 버는 사람들이 실제로 빠지는 두 번째 함정은, 가격을 높게 매기면 가치가 있다고 생각하는 '가격 프리미엄 역설(price premium paradox)'에 빠지는 거예요. 그런데 가격이 너무 높으면 고객 획득(acquisition)에 오히려 악영향을 줘서 대부분 사람들에게는 의미가 없어져요.
text_zh: 赚钱产品容易掉进的第二个坑就是价格溢价悖论(price premium paradox)——你觉得定价高就代表价值高，但价格定得太离谱，反而影响获客(acquisition)，结果大部分人都觉得跟自己没关系了。
text_es: La segunda trampa en la que caen los que generan dinero es que se meten en la paradoja del precio premium, donde piensan que cobrar caro en realidad indica valor, pero tu precio está tan alto que empiezas a lastimar tu captación de clientes, entonces simplemente se vuelve irrelevante para la mayoría de la gente.
context: Madhavan continues explaining founder traps, now focusing on 'moneymaker archetype' companies that prioritize monetization over acquisition. He's describing the price premium paradox - a common mistake where founders believe that higher prices automatically signal higher value to customers. However, when prices become too high, they actually harm customer acquisition because the product becomes unaffordable or irrelevant to most potential buyers.
vocabulary_highlights: price premium paradox, hurting your acquisition, becomes irrelevant

speaker: Madhavan Ramanujam
text: So for instance, if you're a marketing automation AI product and you save, let's say, three weeks of work that actually needs to be done to actually get stuff in a dashboard that can be analyzed by marketing managers, the way you create the need is ask about existing processes and say, 'Okay, so just so I understand, all of this stuff actually takes you three weeks to put data together to actually have meaningful dashboards for your marketing managers to take action. What if that was available to you instantaneously?' Oh, you have now just created a need, right?
text_ko: 예를 들어서, 만약 당신이 마케팅 자동화 AI 제품을 만들고 있고, 마케팅 매니저들이 분석할 수 있는 대시보드에 필요한 작업을 실제로 세 주를 절약할 수 있다고 가정해볼게요. 그러면 필요성을 창출하는 방법은 기존 프로세스에 대해 질문하는 거예요. '아, 그러니까 제가 이해한 바로는, 이 모든 작업을 데이터로 정리해서 마케팅 매니저들이 활용할 수 있는 의미 있는 대시보드를 만드는 데 세 주가 걸린다는 거죠? 만약 그게 즉시 가능하다면 어떨까요?' 이렇게 하면 필요성을 만들어낸 거죠.
text_zh: 比如说，如果你做的是营销自动化AI产品，能够节省三周的工作量——就是那种需要整理数据、搭建仪表板(dashboard)让营销经理分析的工作，那你创造需求的方法就是先问他们现在的流程，然后说："我理解一下啊，你们现在把这些数据整理出来，做成有用的仪表板给营销经理做决策，得花三周时间对吧？那如果这个东西能马上就给你呢？"这样一问，需求不就出来了吗？
text_es: Por ejemplo, digamos que tienes un producto de IA para automatización de marketing y que ahorras, no sé, tres semanas de trabajo que realmente se necesitan para tener todo listo en un dashboard que los gerentes de marketing puedan analizar. La manera de crear esa necesidad es preguntar sobre los procesos actuales y decir: "Bueno, para que entienda bien, ¿todo esto realmente les toma tres semanas juntar los datos para tener dashboards útiles que sus gerentes de marketing puedan usar para tomar decisiones? ¿Y si eso estuviera disponible al instante?" Ahí acabas de crear una necesidad, ¿no?
context: Lenny asks about mastering negotiations, and Madhavan is explaining one of three key components: value selling. Specifically, he's teaching how to 'create needs' rather than just discover them during sales conversations. He provides a concrete example of how a marketing automation AI company should approach potential customers by first understanding their current time-consuming processes, then positioning their solution as an immediate alternative to create urgency and need.
vocabulary_highlights: create the need, meaningful dashboards, available to you instantaneously

speaker: Madhavan Ramanujam
text: The right way to think about an ROI model is to actually co-create it with your customers from day one, which means agree and validate on the assumptions and the inputs. So like, 'Hey, how long does this process take today? How many engineers are there?' So you create ask questions that are all inputs to an ROI model. And if you have done that process and the customer agrees on all the inputs, they're very unlikely to push back on the output of an ROI model.
text_ko: ROI 모델(ROI model)을 생각할 때 올바른 방법은 처음부터 고객과 함께 공동으로 만들어 가는 거예요. 즉, 가정(assumptions)과 입력값(inputs)에 대해 합의하고 검증하는 거죠. 예를 들어 “지금 이 프로세스는 보통 얼마나 걸리나요? 엔지니어는 몇 명이나 투입되나요?”처럼 ROI 모델의 모든 입력값에 해당하는 질문들을 던지는 거예요. 그런 과정을 거쳐 고객이 모든 입력값에 동의하면, 그들이 ROI 모델의 출력(output)을 문제 삼을 가능성은 거의 없어요.
text_zh: 做ROI模型(投资回报率模型)的正确思路其实就是从第一天开始就和客户一起来搞，也就是说要在假设和输入数据上达成一致并验证。比如说，"嘿，这个流程现在要花多长时间？有多少工程师参与？"这样问一些问题，这些都是ROI模型的输入数据。如果你做了这个过程，客户也认同所有的输入数据，那他们基本上不太可能对ROI模型的结果有异议。
text_es: La forma correcta de pensar en un modelo de ROI es co-crearlo con tus clientes desde el primer día, o sea, ponerse de acuerdo y validar las suposiciones y los datos de entrada. Entonces, por ejemplo, "Oye, ¿cuánto tiempo toma este proceso actualmente? ¿Cuántos ingenieros tienen?" Así haces preguntas que son todos inputs para un modelo de ROI. Y si ya pasaste por ese proceso y el cliente está de acuerdo con todos los inputs, es muy poco probable que te cuestionen el resultado del modelo de ROI.
context: Madhavan is continuing his explanation of value selling techniques within negotiation mastery. He's addressing a common founder mistake: showing up with a pre-built ROI (Return on Investment) model after a proof of concept is complete. Instead, he advocates for co-creating the ROI model with customers from the beginning by getting them to agree on all the underlying assumptions and data inputs, making them much more likely to accept the final calculated value.
vocabulary_highlights: co-create it with your customers, validate on the assumptions, push back on the output

speaker: Madhavan Ramanujam
text: So we coached him to go in with a hundred K, plus 10% on any incremental value that you bring, or it's a 500K fixed. So now this is actually a great situation in negotiation. Because if you're price sensitive, you're focused on the hundred K. It's a small fee to actually get started. But the conversation will gravitate towards, 'What is that 10%? How do you measure value?' That's a great conversation to have because now you're talking about, 'How you add value? Where's the value generation? What portion would you take?'
text_ko: 그래서 저희는 그에게 10만 달러(100K)로 시작하되, 당신이 만들어내는 추가 가치(incremental value)에 대해서는 10%를 더 받거나 아니면 고정 50만 달러(500K)로 하라고 조언했어요. 이건 협상에서는 사실 아주 좋은 상황이에요. 왜냐하면 가격에 민감한 경우(price sensitive) 사람들은 10만 달러에만 집중하거든요. 시작하기엔 작은 수수료예요. 그런데 대화는 자연스럽게 ‘그 10%가 뭔가요? 가치를 어떻게 측정하죠?’로 흘러가요. 그게 오히려 훌륭한 대화예요. 이제 ‘어떻게 가치를 더하나요? 가치 창출은 어디서 일어나죠? 그 중 얼마를 가져가나요?’ 같은 얘기를 할 수 있으니까요.
text_zh: 所以我们指导他这样谈：要么是10万打底，然后你带来的任何增值部分再抽10%，要么就是50万包干。这样一来谈判就很有意思了。如果对方比较在意价格，注意力就会放在那10万上，觉得这个启动费用不算高。但话题很快就会转到"那10%是怎么算的？你们怎么衡量价值？"这种讨论就很棒了，因为现在你们聊的是"你怎么创造价值？价值从哪儿来？你要分多少？"
text_es: Le aconsejamos que entrara con cien mil, más un 10% sobre cualquier valor adicional que aporte, o si no, quinientos mil fijos. Entonces ahora tienes una situación buenísima para negociar. Porque si te preocupa el precio, te enfocas en los cien mil. Es una tarifa chica para empezar. Pero la conversación se va a ir hacia "¿Qué es ese 10%? ¿Cómo miden el valor?" Y esa es una conversación excelente porque ya estás hablando de "¿Cómo agregas valor? ¿Dónde se genera el valor? ¿Qué porcentaje te llevarías?"
context: Madhavan is sharing a specific negotiation hack for founders who lack courage to ask for higher prices. He describes coaching a founder who believed the customer's budget was $100K but felt their product could justify $500K. Instead of choosing one price, he suggests offering two pricing model options: a lower base price with outcome-based upside, or a higher fixed price. This approach shifts the conversation from pure price negotiation to value discussion.
vocabulary_highlights: coached him to go in with, conversation will gravitate towards, incremental value

speaker: Madhavan Ramanujam
text: Yeah, AI pricing is very different from the previous vintage of companies. Why is that so? Because AI founders need to tackle monetization from the very early days, like day one in their seed stage pre-seed kind of thing, which was not probably the focus for the previous SaaS companies. Why is that? So because of two reasons. One, for the first time there's cost dynamics to actually navigate. So you need to think about monetization from day one. But there's also a more critical reason, which is value capture.
text_ko: 맞아요. AI 가격 책정(AI pricing)은 이전 세대의 기업들과는 확실히 달라요. 왜 그러냐면 AI 창업자들은 시드(seed)나 프리시드(pre-seed) 단계의 시작부터 바로 수익화(monetization)를 고민해야 하기 때문이에요. 이전의 SaaS(Software as a Service) 회사들에겐 아마 그게 주된 관심사가 아니었죠. 이유는 두 가지예요. 하나는 이제 실제로 관리해야 할 비용 동학(cost dynamics)이 생겼다는 거예요. 그래서 첫날부터 수익화(monetization)를 생각해야 하고, 더 중요한 이유는 바로 가치 포착(value capture)이에요.
text_zh: 对，AI定价跟之前那一批公司确实很不一样。为什么呢？因为AI创业者从一开始就得考虑怎么赚钱，基本上从种子轮(seed stage)甚至更早的时候就得想这个问题，而之前的SaaS公司可能不会这么早就考虑这个。为什么会这样？主要有两个原因。第一个，AI公司第一次真正面临成本控制的问题，所以从第一天开始就得想着怎么变现。但还有一个更关键的原因，就是价值捕获(value capture)的问题。
text_es: Sí, la estrategia de precios para AI es muy distinta a la generación anterior de empresas. ¿Por qué pasa esto? Porque los fundadores de AI necesitan abordar la monetización desde los primeros días, tipo desde el día uno en su etapa seed o pre-seed, lo cual probablemente no era el foco para las empresas SaaS anteriores. ¿Y por qué es así? Por dos razones. Primero, por primera vez hay dinámicas de costos que realmente tienes que manejar. Entonces necesitas pensar en la monetización desde el día uno. Pero también hay una razón más crítica, que es la captura de valor (value capture).
context: Lenny asks how AI pricing differs from traditional software pricing strategies. Madhavan explains that AI companies face fundamentally different challenges compared to previous generations of SaaS companies. Unlike traditional software companies that could focus on growth first and monetization later, AI companies must address pricing from day one due to two key factors: significant cost dynamics from AI infrastructure, and the need to capture value immediately before training customers to expect low prices.
vocabulary_highlights: previous vintage of companies, tackle monetization, cost dynamics to actually navigate

speaker: Madhavan Ramanujam
text: When we talk about pricing, many people quickly gravitate to dollar figures. That's just a price point, that's a dollar figure. But when we think about price, we think about it as a measure. Like liter is a measure of volume, price is a measure of value. And when you think of it this way, it really stands for, do people actually want your product and would they actually buy it?
text_ko: 가격 얘기할 때 많은 사람들이 금액으로 곧장 생각을 좁혀버려요. 그건 그냥 가격대(price point), 달러 액수(dollar figure)에 불과해요. 하지만 가격을 측정의 관점으로 보면 달라요. 리터(liter)가 부피를 재는 단위인 것처럼, 가격은 가치의 척도예요. 이렇게 보면 가격은 결국 사람들이 그 제품을 진짜로 원해서 실제로 구매할지를 보여주는 지표예요.
text_zh: 说到定价这个事儿，很多人一上来就想着具体多少钱。其实那只是个价格点，就是个数字而已。但我们考虑价格的时候，应该把它当成一个衡量标准。就像升是用来衡量体积的，价格其实是用来衡量价值的。你这么一想就明白了，价格真正反映的是——大家到底想不想要你的产品，会不会真的掏钱买。
text_es: Cuando hablamos de precios, mucha gente se va directo a las cifras en pesos. Pero eso es solo un punto de precio, una cifra nada más. Sin embargo, cuando pensamos en el precio, lo vemos como una medida. Así como el litro mide volumen, el precio mide valor. Y cuando lo ves de esta manera, realmente lo que te está diciendo es: ¿la gente realmente quiere tu producto y estaría dispuesta a comprarlo?
context: Lenny asks Madhavan to introduce the concept of pricing strategy and how to think about it differently. Madhavan explains that most people think about pricing as just dollar amounts, but he argues that price should be viewed as a measurement tool - similar to how liters measure volume, price measures value. This reframing helps entrepreneurs understand that pricing conversations are really about validating whether customers actually want and will purchase their product, which he calls the willingness to pay conversation.
vocabulary_highlights: quickly gravitate to, stands for

speaker: Madhavan Ramanujam
text: Back in the day, probably a decade ago, I used to say pricing needs to sit in finance, because my view was finance would be the counterbalance to sales, especially if you have sales coming up with pricing in a B2B situation, you can set all the pricing you want, it's human having a human conversation. So how do you put checks and balance in some of that?
text_ko: 예전, 한 10년 전쯤에는 가격 결정(pricing)은 재무(finance)에 있어야 한다고 말하곤 했어요. 제 생각엔 재무가 영업(sales)에 대한 균형추 역할을 해줄 거라고 봤거든요. 특히 기업 간 거래(B2B) 상황에서 영업이 가격을 먼저 들고 나오면, 사람끼리 하는 대화라서 알아서 마음대로 가격을 정해버릴 수 있죠. 그래서 그걸 어떻게 견제(checks and balances)하고 균형을 잡을지가 문제였어요.
text_zh: 以前，大概十年前吧，我一直说定价这块儿应该放在财务部门，因为我觉得财务可以制衡销售，特别是在B2B的情况下，如果让销售来定价，你想定什么价都行，反正都是人和人在聊嘛。所以怎么在这里面加一些制衡机制呢？
text_es: Hace tiempo, hace como una década, yo solía decir que el pricing tenía que estar en finanzas, porque mi punto de vista era que finanzas sería el contrapeso de ventas, especialmente si tienes a ventas definiendo precios en una situación B2B, puedes poner los precios que quieras, al final es gente hablando con gente. Entonces, ¿cómo pones controles y equilibrios en todo eso?
context: Lenny asks which department should own pricing strategy within an organization. Madhavan shares how his thinking has evolved over time. He explains that he previously believed pricing should sit in finance because finance teams could serve as a counterbalance to sales teams, who might be tempted to negotiate prices down during deal conversations. The phrase 'checks and balance' refers to creating organizational controls to prevent any one department from making pricing decisions that could hurt the company's profitability.
vocabulary_highlights: back in the day, counterbalance, checks and balance

speaker: Madhavan Ramanujam
text: 72% of innovations actually fail from a monetization or commercial perspective, simply because entrepreneurs or companies did not do the check earlier on. Had they done it, they could have probably pivoted the product, built things in a different way and built something that was more meaningful.
text_ko: 사실 혁신의 약 72%가 수익화(monetization)나 상업적 관점에서 실패해요. 대부분 창업자나 기업이 그걸 미리 검증(check)하지 않았기 때문이죠. 만약 초기에 검증했더라면 제품을 피벗(pivot)하거나 접근 방식을 바꿔 훨씬 더 의미 있는 결과물을 만들 수 있었을 거예요.
text_zh: 其实有72%的创新从变现或者商业角度来说都是失败的，就是因为创业者或者公司前期没有做好这个检验工作。如果他们早点做这个功课的话，很可能就会调整产品方向(pivot)，换个思路去做，最后做出来的东西会更有价值。
text_es: El 72% de las innovaciones fracasan desde el punto de vista de monetización o comercialización, simplemente porque los emprendedores o las empresas no hicieron la validación desde el principio. Si la hubieran hecho, probablemente podrían haber pivotado el producto, construir las cosas de manera diferente y crear algo que realmente tuviera más impacto en el mercado.
context: Lenny asks what motivated Madhavan to write his book 'Monetizing Innovation.' Madhavan explains that he was frustrated by companies following a 'spray and pray' approach - building products first and then hoping to monetize them later. He shares a key statistic from their research showing that nearly three-quarters of innovations fail commercially because companies don't validate customer willingness to pay early in the development process. This failure rate could be reduced if companies tested pricing concepts before building the full product.
vocabulary_highlights: spray and pray, pivoted the product

speaker: Madhavan Ramanujam
text: You cannot prioritize a product roadmap without having a willingness to pay conversation. If you're just prioritizing based on what you think or what you feel or technical resources, you're getting it wrong. Literally, you can prioritize what you are building based on what customers need, what they value, and what they're willing to pay for.
text_ko: 제품 로드맵(product roadmap)의 우선순위를 정하려면 반드시 지불 의향(willingness to pay)에 대한 얘기가 있어야 해요. 단지 내가 생각하는 것, 느낌, 혹은 기술 자원(technical resources)만 보고 우선순위를 매기면 잘못하는 거예요. 실제로는 고객이 필요로 하는 것, 고객이 가치 있게 여기는 것, 그리고 고객이 지불할 의향이 있는 것에 기반해 우리가 만드는 것의 우선순위를 정해야 해요.
text_zh: 不跟客户聊聊他们愿意为什么付钱，你就没法做产品路线图(product roadmap)的优先级排序。如果你只是凭自己的想法、感觉，或者看技术资源来排优先级，那就搞错了。说白了，你应该根据客户真正需要什么、看重什么、愿意掏钱买什么，来决定先做哪些功能。
text_es: No puedes priorizar una hoja de ruta de producto (product roadmap) sin tener una conversación sobre la disposición a pagar (willingness to pay). Si solo estás priorizando basándote en lo que piensas o lo que sientes, o en los recursos técnicos que tienes, la estás regando. La neta es que puedes priorizar lo que vas a desarrollar basándote en lo que los clientes realmente necesitan, lo que valoran, y por lo que están dispuestos a pagar.
context: Lenny asks for examples of companies that successfully used willingness to pay conversations. Madhavan shares the story of a two-sided marketplace that tested customer willingness to pay for different features before building them. He emphasizes that product teams cannot effectively prioritize their roadmaps using only internal opinions or technical constraints - they need customer willingness to pay data. This insight helps teams focus their limited resources on building the 20% of features that drive 80% of customer value and payment intent.
vocabulary_highlights: you're getting it wrong, literally

speaker: Madhavan Ramanujam
text: People are absolutely meaningless, relatively super smart. What I mean by that is, if you go and ask someone, 'How much should I charge?' You'll get a meaningless answer. But if you actually ask it in a relative way, people actually give responses that are meaningful.
text_ko: 사람들은 절대적인 기준에선 별 의미가 없지만, 상대적인 기준에선 엄청 똑똑해요. 제 말은, 누군가에게 “얼마를 받아야 할까요?”라고 딱 물어보면 쓸모없는 답이 돌아올 거예요. 그런데 같은 질문을 비교 방식으로, 예를 들어 “이 경우에는 얼마, 저 경우에는 얼마로 책정해야 할까요?”처럼 상대적으로 물어보면 사람들이 의미 있는 답을 해줘요.
text_zh: 人们回答绝对性问题的时候完全没谱，但回答相对性问题的时候特别靠谱。我的意思是，如果你直接问别人"我应该定价多少？"你得到的答案基本上没什么用。但如果你换个方式，用相对比较的方法来问，人们给出的回答就很有参考价值了。
text_es: La gente es totalmente inútil para dar respuestas absolutas, pero súper inteligente cuando se trata de comparaciones. Lo que quiero decir es esto: si vas y le preguntas a alguien "¿Cuánto debería cobrar?", te va a dar una respuesta que no te sirve para nada. Pero si realmente le preguntas de manera relativa, la gente sí te da respuestas que tienen sentido.
context: Lenny asks how to actually conduct willingness to pay conversations with customers. Madhavan explains his first method for having these conversations without directly asking customers to set prices. He uses a humorous phrase to describe how people struggle with absolute pricing questions but excel at relative comparisons. Instead of asking 'What should I charge?', he suggests asking customers to compare your product's value to established products like Salesforce, using an indexed scale where the competitor equals 100 and customers rate where your product falls relative to that benchmark.
vocabulary_highlights: absolutely meaningless, relatively super smart, indexed at

speaker: Madhavan Ramanujam
text: Segmentation needs to be based on what customers need, what they value, and what are they willing to pay for, and how do you productize package to different segments. So the key lesson that I want your listeners to take away is, you need to be able to productize to segments. If you're trying to build a product and try to position it to different segments, you already lost the battle.
text_ko: 세분화(segmentation)는 고객이 무엇을 필요로 하는지, 무엇을 가치 있게 여기는지, 무엇에 기꺼이 비용을 지불할지를 기준으로 해야 하고, 각 세그먼트(segments)에 어떻게 제품화(productize)·패키징(packaging)할지 설계해야 해요. 제가 듣는 분들에게 전하고 싶은 핵심은 세그먼트별로 제품화할 수 있어야 한다는 점이에요. 제품 하나를 만들어 놓고 그걸 여러 세그먼트에 억지로 포지셔닝(positioning)하려 하면 이미 실패한 거예요.
text_zh: 做市场细分得基于客户真正需要什么、看重什么，还有他们愿意为什么买单，然后你怎么针对不同细分市场去做产品化包装。所以我希望听众们记住的关键一点就是，你必须能够针对细分市场做产品化。如果你想着先做个产品出来，然后再去不同的细分市场定位，那你这仗已经败了。
text_es: La segmentación tiene que basarse en lo que los clientes necesitan, lo que valoran, y por lo que están dispuestos a pagar, y cómo productizas y empaquetas para diferentes segmentos. Entonces la lección clave que quiero que se lleven tus oyentes es que necesitas poder productizar para segmentos específicos. Si estás tratando de construir un producto y después intentas posicionarlo para diferentes segmentos, ya perdiste la batalla desde el principio.
context: Lenny asks why segmentation is so important for pricing strategy. Madhavan explains that most companies misunderstand segmentation, treating it as a demographics or persona exercise rather than a needs-based approach. He argues that true segmentation must be based on customer needs, values, and willingness to pay, and companies must build different products for different segments rather than building one product and trying to position it differently. The phrase 'you already lost the battle' emphasizes that trying to make one product appeal to all segments is a losing strategy.
vocabulary_highlights: productize to segments, lost the battle

speaker: Madhavan Ramanujam
text: We usually say how you charge is way more important than how much you charge. Take a quick example and then bring the point home and then we can talk about why this is actually essential.
text_ko: 보통은 '얼마를 받느냐'보다 '어떻게 받느냐'가 훨씬 더 중요하다고 말해요. 간단한 예를 하나 들어 요점을 확실히 보여드리고, 그다음에 왜 이게 실제로 필수적인지 이야기해볼게요.
text_zh: 我们经常说，你怎么收费比收多少钱重要得多。我先举个简单的例子，然后把这个道理说透，接下来咱们再聊聊为什么这点其实特别关键。
text_es: Siempre decimos que cómo cobras es mucho más importante que cuánto cobras. Te doy un ejemplo rápido para que se entienda bien el punto, y después hablamos de por qué esto es realmente clave.
context: Lenny introduces the topic of pricing models - the mechanisms companies use to charge customers rather than just the amount they charge. Madhavan emphasizes that the pricing model (how you charge) is more critical than the specific price point (how much you charge). He's about to illustrate this concept with examples from Michelin tires and other companies that transformed their businesses by changing their charging method rather than their prices. The phrase 'bring the point home' means to make the concept clear and convincing through examples.
vocabulary_highlights: bring the point home

speaker: Maggie Crowley
speaker_expertise: Product Management, Product Strategy, Leadership Development
text: If you ever find yourself saying something like, that's not my job, that's probably a thing you should do. And you know what? It probably isn't your job and it probably is someone else's job and you can spend your life getting frustrated at that or you can just get over and get the work done. And people who are willing to just get the work done will move faster. Their products will be more successful and they probably aren't carrying around all that anger and crappy emotion.
text_ko: 혹시 '그건 내 일이 아니에요'라는 말을 하게 되는 자신을 발견하면, 오히려 그걸 해야 할 일이 생긴 경우가 많아요. 그리고 사실 그게 진짜 내 일이 아닐 수도 있고 다른 사람 책임일 수도 있어요. 근데 그걸 가지고 평생 답답해할 수도 있고, 그냥 털고 일을 해치울 수도 있어요. 일을 그냥 해내는 사람들은 더 빨리 움직여요. 그들의 제품은 더 성공하고, 쓸데없는 분노나 안 좋은 감정을 안고 다니지도 않아요.
text_zh: 如果你发现自己在说"这不是我的活儿"，那这事儿你可能就应该去做。你知道吗？这确实可能不是你的分内事，确实可能是别人该干的活，你可以为这事儿郁闷一辈子，也可以想开点儿直接把事情搞定。那些愿意直接上手干活的人会走得更快，他们的产品会更成功，而且他们也不会背着那么多负面情绪和怨气。
text_es: Si alguna vez te encuentras diciendo algo como "eso no es mi trabajo", probablemente sea justo lo que deberías hacer. ¿Y sabes qué? Probablemente no sea tu trabajo y probablemente sí sea el trabajo de otra persona, y puedes pasarte la vida frustrándote por eso o simplemente superarlo y hacer el trabajo. Y la gente que está dispuesta a hacer el trabajo sin más va a avanzar más rápido. Sus productos van a ser más exitosos y probablemente no anden cargando toda esa rabia y emociones tóxicas.
context: Lenny asks Maggie about the common threads she's seen across the best product managers she's worked with, hired, and managed. Maggie explains her third key trait, which she calls 'carrying the water' - being willing to do the unglamorous work that needs to get done regardless of whose official responsibility it is. She emphasizes that PMs who succeed are those who focus on getting work done rather than getting frustrated about job boundaries.
vocabulary_highlights: get over, carrying around, crappy emotion

speaker: Maggie Crowley
speaker_expertise: Product Management, Product Strategy, Leadership Development
text: Because as a PM, for better or for worse, and maybe this is not how we all want it to be, but you're oftentimes the emotional center of the team and it's your job to keep people motivated, keep people excited, keep them bought into the project, and you just have to keep that optimism going and it's hard work and part of it can be just like, you know what? Let me take that on. I'll do this thing. I'll hop on this sales call, I'll implement this with the customer. You just have to do whatever it takes.
text_ko: 프로덕트 매니저(Product Manager, PM)로서, 좋든 나쁘든—그리고 꼭 우리가 모두 원하던 건 아닐 수도 있지만—대개 팀의 정서적 중심이 되는 경우가 많아요. 사람들의 동기를 유지하고, 열정을 계속 살리고, 프로젝트에 진심으로 몰입하게 만드는 게 당신의 역할이에요. 그 낙관적인 분위기를 계속 이어가는 건 정말 고된 일이에요. 그래서 때로는 ‘내가 할게’ 하고 나서는 수밖에 없어요. 이건 내가 맡아서 할게, 영업 콜(sales call)에 직접 나가고 고객과 함께 구현해볼게 같은 식으로요. 필요한 건 뭐든 해야 해요.
text_zh: 因为作为PM(产品经理)，不管好坏，可能这也不是我们都希望的样子，但你经常就是团队的情感核心，你的工作就是让大家保持动力，让大家保持兴奋，让他们对项目有信心，你得一直保持这种乐观态度，这真的很累，有时候就得想，算了，这事我来扛吧。这个我来做，我来参加这个销售电话，我来跟客户对接实施。反正就是不管什么事都得上。
text_es: Porque como PM, para bien o para mal, y quizás no es como todos quisiéramos que fuera, pero muchas veces eres el centro emocional del equipo y tu trabajo es mantener a la gente motivada, mantenerlos emocionados, que sigan comprometidos con el proyecto, y tienes que mantener ese optimismo y es trabajo duro y parte de eso puede ser simplemente como, ¿sabes qué? Yo me encargo de esto. Yo hago esto. Me meto en esta llamada de ventas, yo lo implemento con el cliente. Tienes que hacer lo que sea necesario.
context: Lenny asks Maggie about the common threads across successful product managers. Maggie is explaining the concept of 'carrying the water' as a PM - being willing to do work that technically isn't your job. She describes how PMs often serve as the emotional center of their teams, responsible for maintaining team morale and motivation while also being willing to jump into any role needed to ensure project success.
vocabulary_highlights: for better or for worse, bought into, hop on, whatever it takes

speaker: Maggie Crowley
speaker_expertise: Product Management, Product Strategy, Leadership Development
text: So many people in the spec or the one pager or something will say, okay, here's the metric that I care about. Here's what I want to move. Awesome. Maybe they'll even write a SQL query, get a dashboard going, figure out what the number is today, that gets you some extra points, but the really, really good PMs remember to follow up. Because especially when you're in management, couple layers up in management, I'm not going to remember to follow up on that feature, but if a PM comes back to me and says, 'Hey, remember we did that thing, here's what happened.' I can't tell you how rare that is and how many times as a leader you might have to ask for that and for the people you don't have to ask that of is one of the best things when I'm looking at PMs and it's easy.
text_ko: 많은 사람들이 스펙이나 원 페이저 같은 데서 "내가 신경 쓰는 지표는 이거고, 내가 바꾸고 싶은 건 이거야"라고 말해요. 멋지죠. 아마 SQL 쿼리도 작성하고 대시보드도 만들어서 오늘의 숫자가 뭔지 알아내는 경우도 있을 거예요. 그건 추가 점수를 주는 거지만, 정말 뛰어난 PM들은 꼭 후속 조치를 잊지 않아요. 특히 관리직에 있으면, 위로 몇 단계 올라가면 그 기능에 대해 후속 조치를 기억하기가 쉽지 않거든요. 그런데 PM이 다시 와서 "이거 했던 거 기억해요? 이렇게 됐어요"라고 말해주면, 그게 얼마나 드문 일인지, 그리고 리더로서 그걸 물어봐야 하는 경우가 얼마나 많은지 알 수 있어요. 그런 걸 물어보지 않아도 되는 PM들은 제가 PM을 평가할 때 가장 좋은 점 중 하나예요. 정말 쉽거든요.
text_zh: 很多人在写产品需求文档(spec)或者一页纸总结的时候会说，好，这就是我关心的指标，这就是我想要推动的东西。挺好的。可能他们还会写个SQL查询，搞个仪表板(dashboard)，看看今天的数字是多少，这能给你加点分，但真正优秀的产品经理(PM)会记得跟进。因为特别是当你在管理层，或者管理层的好几级上面时，我不会记得去跟进那个功能，但如果一个PM回来跟我说："嘿，还记得我们做的那个事吗，结果是这样的。" 我没法告诉你这有多么少见，作为领导你可能要主动问多少次才能得到这种反馈，而那些你不用主动问的人，这是我看PM时最看重的品质之一，而且很容易识别。
text_es: Muchísima gente en las especificaciones o en el resumen ejecutivo te va a decir: "Bueno, esta es la métrica que me importa, esto es lo que quiero mover." Perfecto. A lo mejor hasta escriben una consulta SQL, montan un dashboard, averiguan cuál es el número actual - eso ya te suma puntos extra - pero los PMs realmente buenos se acuerdan de hacer seguimiento. Porque sobre todo cuando estás en management, un par de niveles arriba en la jerarquía, yo no me voy a acordar de hacer seguimiento a esa funcionalidad, pero si un PM viene y me dice: "Oye, ¿te acuerdas de esa cosa que hicimos? Mira lo que pasó." No te puedo explicar lo raro que es eso y cuántas veces como líder tienes que andar pidiendo esa información. Y con las personas a las que no les tienes que pedir eso... es una de las mejores cosas cuando evalúo PMs, y es súper fácil.
context: Lenny asks Maggie about the three traits that make great product managers. Maggie is explaining her second trait: following up on results. She describes how many PMs set metrics and track them initially, but the exceptional ones remember to circle back and report on what actually happened with their launches and initiatives, which is surprisingly rare and highly valued by leadership.
vocabulary_highlights: gets you some extra points, couple layers up, I can't tell you how rare that is, circle back

speaker: Maggie Crowley
speaker_expertise: Product Management, Product Strategy, Leadership Development
text: Those things to me, communication, super important, analytical ability, really, really important. The ability to look at a, especially if you're doing something that has a user experience component, the ability to look at that and understand if it's going to work and build up intuition around that, also really important. Those are things that I would see as sort of basics of the role. These are the things that make you great at the role and strategy to me, and hopefully we'll talk about strategy in a bit. It's one tiny slice. You do a strategy, but it's 5% of the work that you do.
text_ko: 저한테는 그런 것들, 커뮤니케이션(communication)이 되게 중요하고 분석 능력(analytical ability)도 정말, 정말 중요해요. 특히 사용자 경험(user experience)이 관련된 일을 한다면 그걸 보고 잘 작동할지 판단하고 그에 대한 직관을 쌓는 능력도 정말 중요해요. 저는 이런 것들을 역할의 기본이라고 봐요. 이런 것들이 그 역할에서 훌륭하게 만들어주고요, 전략(strategy)은 제게 아주 작은 한 조각이에요 — 조금 있다가 전략에 대해서도 얘기하겠지만요. 전략을 한다고 해도 전체 일의 약 5% 정도에 불과해요.
text_zh: 在我看来，沟通能力，超级重要，分析能力，真的真的很重要。还有就是判断能力，特别是如果你做的事情涉及用户体验的话，你得能看出来这个东西行不行得通，慢慢培养这方面的直觉，这个也特别关键。这些我觉得都是这个岗位的基本功。真正让你在这个岗位上做得出色的，还有战略思维，希望我们待会儿能聊聊战略这块儿。其实战略只是很小的一部分。你是要做战略规划，但这可能只占你工作的5%。
text_es: Para mí, la comunicación es súper importante, la capacidad analítica también es clave, de verdad. La habilidad de ver algo, sobre todo si estás trabajando en algo que tiene componente de experiencia del usuario (user experience), poder analizarlo y entender si va a funcionar y desarrollar intuición al respecto, eso también es fundamental. Esas son cosas que yo veo como los básicos del puesto. Estas son las cosas que te hacen destacar en el rol, y la estrategia para mí - y ojalá podamos hablar de estrategia en un rato - es solo una pequeña parte. Sí, haces estrategia, pero es el 5% del trabajo que realizas.
context: Lenny points out that Maggie's three traits for great PMs are different from the typical answers people give (communication, collaboration, vision, strategy). Maggie responds by distinguishing between what she considers the basics of being a PM versus what makes someone truly great at the role. She argues that while skills like communication and analytical thinking are important fundamentals, her three traits are what separate good PMs from great ones.
vocabulary_highlights: build up intuition, sort of basics, one tiny slice

speaker: Maggie Crowley
speaker_expertise: Product Management, Product Strategy, Leadership Development
text: The one I like to have in this area is that people who are really excited about being data-driven, to me that is oftentimes a red flag for their product thinking, especially if it's an executive who's saying things like, oh, so we make all our decisions with our dashboards. To me that says that the team is over-emphasizing quantitative data at the expense of qualitative data and they're not using good judgment. They probably don't do a lot of direct user research. They don't really understand the humans who are using the thing, what they need, what they care about, and they're managing via a dashboard.
text_ko: 이 분야에서 제가 특히 신경 쓰이는 건, 스스로를 '데이터 기반(data-driven)'이라고 너무 열성적으로 얘기하는 사람들이에요. 개인적으로 그런 태도는 제품 사고(product thinking)에 대해 자주 레드 플래그라고 생각해요. 특히 임원(executive)들이 "우리는 모든 결정을 대시보드(dashboard)로 내린다"고 말하면 더더욱요. 제겐 그게 팀이 정성 데이터(qualitative data)를 희생하면서 정량 데이터(quantitative data)만 과도하게 신뢰하고 있고, 제대로 된 판단을 못 하고 있다는 신호로 들려요. 아마 직접 사용자 리서치(direct user research)를 많이 안 하고, 실제로 그걸 쓰는 사람들—그들이 무엇을 필요로 하고, 무엇을 중요하게 여기는지—을 잘 이해하지 못하는 경우가 많아요. 대신 대시보드(dashboard)로 관리하고 있는 거죠.
text_zh: 我在这方面有个观点，就是那些特别热衷于说自己是"数据驱动"的人，在我看来这往往是他们产品思维有问题的一个危险信号，特别是当高管说"哎呀，我们所有决策都是看仪表板(dashboard)做的"这种话的时候。这种说法在我听来就是团队过分看重定量数据，忽略了定性数据，而且缺乏判断力。他们可能很少做直接的用户研究，根本不了解使用产品的真实用户——不知道用户需要什么，在意什么，完全就是对着仪表板在做管理。
text_es: Lo que me gusta mencionar en este tema es que cuando alguien está súper emocionado por ser "data-driven", para mí eso muchas veces es una bandera roja en cuanto a su forma de pensar el producto, especialmente si es un ejecutivo que dice cosas como "ah, nosotros tomamos todas nuestras decisiones con nuestros dashboards". Para mí eso significa que el equipo le está dando demasiada importancia a los datos cuantitativos y está dejando de lado los datos cualitativos, y no están usando buen criterio. Probablemente no hacen mucha investigación directa con usuarios. Realmente no entienden a las personas que están usando el producto, qué necesitan, qué les importa, y están gestionando todo desde un dashboard.
context: Lenny asks Maggie about contrarian opinions she holds about product management. Maggie shares her view that when people or executives emphasize being 'data-driven,' it often signals poor product thinking. She explains that this typically means teams are over-relying on quantitative metrics while neglecting qualitative insights from user research and losing touch with the actual humans using their products.
vocabulary_highlights: red flag, over-emphasizing, at the expense of, managing via a dashboard

speaker: Maggie Crowley
speaker_expertise: Product Management, Product Strategy, Leadership Development
text: Really if you're going to make good content, you have to sanitize and frameworkize the thing that you're working on. And then slowly, I think for a lot of people who are reading it and looking at it, their thinking starts to become, well look how well I did this framework. Look how well I implemented this thing. And they lose touch with the point which is creating impact. And so all of this content makes it really noisy and then makes people think that, oh, if I just do these things that I'll get what I want.
text_ko: 정말 좋은 콘텐츠를 만들려면 작업 중인 내용을 정제(sanitize)하고 프레임화(frameworkize)해야 해요. 그러고 나면 그걸 읽고 보는 많은 사람들은 점점 “봐, 내가 이 프레임(framework)을 얼마나 잘 만들었는지”, “내가 이걸 얼마나 잘 구현했는지”라는 식으로 생각하기 시작해요. 그리고 정작 중요한, 즉 영향력(impact)을 만드는 것과는 점점 멀어져요. 결국 이런 콘텐츠들이 넘쳐나면서 잡음만 커지고, 사람들은 “아, 이걸 그냥 따라하면 내가 원하는 걸 얻을 수 있겠네”라고 생각하게 되는 거예요.
text_zh: 说实话，要做出好内容的话，你得把你在做的事情先梳理清楚，搭个框架出来。然后慢慢地，我觉得很多人看了这些内容之后，思维就变成了"你看我这个框架用得多好，你看我执行得多到位"。结果就忘了最核心的点——创造影响力。所以这些内容就变得特别嘈杂，让人觉得"哦，我只要照着这些步骤做就能得到我想要的结果了"。
text_es: Mira, si de verdad quieres crear buen contenido, tienes que limpiar y estructurar lo que estás trabajando con algún marco de trabajo (framework). Y después, poco a poco, creo que mucha gente que lo lee y lo ve empieza a pensar: "qué bien que apliqué este marco, qué bien que implementé esto." Y se les olvida el punto principal, que es generar impacto real. Entonces todo este contenido genera mucho ruido y hace que la gente piense que si simplemente hacen estas cosas van a conseguir lo que quieren.
context: Lenny asks Maggie about her contrarian opinions on product content, which is relevant since they both create content about product management. Maggie explains how creating good content requires distilling complex work into clean frameworks, but this can mislead readers into thinking that following frameworks is the goal rather than creating actual business impact. She argues this creates noise in the product management field.
vocabulary_highlights: sanitize and frameworkize, lose touch with, makes it really noisy

speaker: Manik Gupta
text: I'm a strong technology optimist. There's always a lot of narrative these days around technology and maybe a little bit more pessimism, and I find that bizarre. I'm just such a strong technology advocate and optimist, because I feel technology's such a strong force for good.
text_ko: 저는 기술(technology)에 대해 아주 낙관적인 편이에요. 요즘은 기술을 둘러싼 이야기들이 많은데, 오히려 비관적인 목소리가 더 커진 것 같아 좀 이상해요. 저는 기술을 강력히 지지하는 사람이자 낙관론자예요. 기술이 세상에 선한 영향을 주는 강한 힘이라고 믿거든요.
text_zh: 我是个坚定的技术乐观派。现在总有很多关于技术的讨论，而且可能还带着点悲观情绪，我觉得这挺奇怪的。我就是特别支持技术发展，特别乐观，因为我觉得技术绝对是个正面力量。
text_es: Soy muy optimista con la tecnología. Últimamente hay mucha conversación sobre la tecnología y quizás un poco más de pesimismo, y me parece rarísimo. Es que soy un defensor y optimista de la tecnología súper convencido, porque siento que la tecnología es una fuerza increíblemente positiva.
context: Lenny asks Manik what are the one or two main things he did that helped him get to where he is today for people early in their careers. Manik explains his second pattern for career success - being a strong technology optimist who believes in using technology to solve real human needs at scale. He contrasts this with current pessimistic narratives about technology and emphasizes how this optimism has guided his choice of projects throughout his career.
vocabulary_highlights: strong force for good, technology advocate, find that bizarre

speaker: Manik Gupta
text: When I joined Google in India in 2008, I started off working on Google Maps and I remember how counterintuitive it was for anybody; my friends and family, a bunch of other folks whom I talked to. Counterintuitive in terms of why would anybody ever use maps on their mobile phone in India?
text_ko: 2008년 인도에서 구글에 합류했을 때 구글 지도(Google Maps) 일을 처음 맡았어요. 친구들이나 가족, 만나봤던 여러 사람들 모두 '인도에서 누가 휴대폰으로 지도를 쓰겠어?'라며 전혀 이해를 못 했던 기억이 나요.
text_zh: 2008年我刚加入谷歌印度的时候，一开始是做谷歌地图的。我记得当时所有人都觉得特别不可思议——我的朋友、家人，还有其他很多我聊过的人。他们都想不通，在印度谁会在手机上用地图啊？
text_es: Cuando me uní a Google en India en 2008, empecé trabajando en Google Maps y recuerdo lo raro que le parecía a todo el mundo; a mis amigos, mi familia, y a un montón de gente con la que hablaba. Les parecía rarísimo la idea de por qué alguien iba a usar mapas en su celular en India.
context: Lenny asks what project or product Manik is most proud of from his career. Manik discusses his work on Google Maps in India, explaining how initially it seemed counterintuitive to build a maps product for India because the country seemed unmappable due to poor addressing systems and people traditionally asked for directions from locals instead of using technology.
vocabulary_highlights: counterintuitive

speaker: Manik Gupta
text: We glamorize successes and we don't talk enough about challenges. I'm really happy that you're asking this. I would give you two times which... I had a lot of learning from both of them, but they were pretty tough times for me.
text_ko: 사람들은 성공만 미화하고 어려움에 대해서는 충분히 이야기하지 않아요. 이런 질문을 해주셔서 정말 기뻐요. 제가 꼽자면 두 번의 시기를 말씀드리겠는데요. 둘 다 많이 배운 시간이었지만 제게는 꽤 힘든 시기였어요.
text_zh: 我们总是把成功说得特别光鲜，但很少聊那些困难和挑战。你能问这个问题我真的很开心。我想跟你分享两个时期，这两段经历让我学到了很多，但当时对我来说真的挺难熬的。
text_es: Tendemos a romantizar los éxitos y no hablamos lo suficiente de los retos. Me da mucho gusto que me preguntes esto. Te diría que hubo dos momentos en los que... aprendí muchísimo de ambos, pero fueron épocas bastante duras para mí.
context: Lenny asks about challenging times in Manik's career, noting that people might see his career as always successful. Manik emphasizes the importance of discussing challenges rather than just successes, and prepares to share two particularly difficult periods from his career - one during the dotcom bust after starting his company, and another during Uber's turbulent period in 2017-2018.
vocabulary_highlights: glamorize successes

speaker: Manik Gupta
text: People can smell fear and pessimism from far. Just like optimism is infectious, so is pessimism. If you're not feeling great as a leader, people will see it. Absolutely. People are not stupid. You have to not fake it. You have to really be motivated to stick it out, and that's what I tried to do at least, and I learned a lot in that.
text_ko: 사람들은 멀리서도 두려움이나 비관을 금방 느껴요. 낙관이 전염되듯이 비관도 전염돼요. 리더로서 기분이 안 좋으면 사람들은 금방 알아차려요. 사람들은 바보가 아니에요. 겉으로만 꾸미면 안 돼요. 진짜로 버티고자 하는 동기와 의지가 있어야 해요. 적어도 저는 그렇게 하려고 노력했고, 그 과정에서 많은 걸 배웠어요.
text_zh: 人们老远就能闻到你的恐惧和悲观情绪。就像乐观会传染一样，悲观也会传染。如果你作为领导者状态不好，大家肯定看得出来。绝对的。大家又不傻。你不能装，必须真的有动力坚持下去，至少我是这么努力做的，从中也学到了很多。
text_es: La gente huele el miedo y el pesimismo de lejos. Igual que el optimismo se contagia, el pesimismo también. Si como líder no te sientes bien, la gente se va a dar cuenta. Totalmente. La gente no es tonta. No puedes fingir. Tienes que estar realmente motivado para aguantar y seguir adelante, y eso es lo que traté de hacer por lo menos, y aprendí muchísimo en el proceso.
context: Manik is describing lessons learned during the challenging dotcom bust period when he was running his startup. He explains how he learned about managing ambiguity and keeping people motivated during tough times, emphasizing that as a leader you cannot fake motivation - people will detect insincerity and your genuine emotional state affects the entire team.
vocabulary_highlights: smell fear and pessimism from far, optimism is infectious, stick it out

speaker: Manik Gupta
text: Build for the world from day one. Understand that there are going to be some nuances that you'll have to solve as you drive adoption in certain markets, but don't over index on building market specific solutions, because consumers have moved on from that kind of a model.
