text_ko: 처음부터 전 세계를 대상으로 설계하세요. 특정 시장에서 채택을 촉진(drive adoption)하다 보면 해결해야 할 미묘한 차이들이 있겠지만, 시장별 솔루션(market-specific solutions) 만드는 데 과도하게 치중하지 마세요. 소비자들은 그런 모델을 이미 넘어섰어요.
text_zh: 从第一天起就要做全球化的产品。你得明白，在不同市场推广的时候肯定会遇到一些细节问题需要解决，但是别太纠结于为特定市场量身定制解决方案，因为现在的消费者已经不吃这一套了。
text_es: Construye pensando en el mercado global desde el primer día. Ten claro que van a surgir ciertos matices que tendrás que resolver conforme vayas ganando tracción en algunos mercados, pero no te enfoques demasiado en crear soluciones súper específicas para cada mercado, porque los consumidores ya superaron ese tipo de modelo.
context: Lenny asks about counterintuitive things Manik has learned about building consumer products. Manik argues against the common belief that you need different products for different global markets. He explains that while localization for language and pricing is necessary, the core user interface patterns and product functionality should be universal, as consumers worldwide now expect similar experiences.
vocabulary_highlights: over index on, moved on from that kind of a model

speaker: Manik Gupta
text: What I define as company product fit. Which is a company essentially is a portfolio of products, and every large company, medium-sized company also has a portfolio. They'll have 10, 20, in some cases hundreds of products in the portfolio. Every company has unique strengths and weaknesses.
text_ko: 제가 말하는 회사-제품 적합성 (company product fit)은, 즉 회사는 본질적으로 여러 제품으로 이뤄진 제품 포트폴리오 (product portfolio)라는 뜻이에요. 대기업이든 중견기업이든 포트폴리오를 갖고 있고 보통 10개, 20개, 경우에 따라 수백 개의 제품을 포함하죠. 모든 회사는 저마다 고유한 강점과 약점이 있어요.
text_zh: 我定义的叫公司产品匹配度(company product fit)。其实公司本质上就是一个产品组合，每个大公司、中等规模的公司都有自己的产品组合。他们会有十几个、二十几个产品，有些情况下甚至几百个产品在这个组合里。每家公司都有自己独特的优势和短板。
text_es: Lo que yo defino como el ajuste entre empresa y producto. Básicamente, una empresa es como una cartera de productos, y toda empresa grande, o incluso mediana, también tiene su portafolio. Van a tener 10, 20, en algunos casos cientos de productos en su cartera. Cada empresa tiene sus fortalezas y debilidades únicas.
context: Lenny asks Manik to explain his concept of company product fit for bigger companies building new products. Manik introduces his framework that comes before finding product market fit - companies must first determine if a new product fits within their portfolio and leverages their unique strengths. He explains that companies are portfolios of products with distinct capabilities, and new products should align with these strengths.

speaker: Manik Gupta
text: Having the right metrics is important, but it's incredible how many times people have the metrics but they don't instrument them. They'll have all these debates, because the product is not instrumented properly. And everybody will talk about the same metric, but they'll have different nuances in terms of, 'Oh, what does it really mean? What is a daily active user?'
text_ko: 지표(metrics)를 제대로 갖추는 건 중요해요. 그런데 그 지표들을 계측(instrument)해 놓지 않은 경우가 얼마나 많은지 정말 놀라워요. 제품을 제대로 계측해 놓지 않아서 온갖 논쟁이 벌어지고, 모두 같은 지표(metrics)에 대해 얘기하지만 “이게 정확히 무슨 뜻이지? 일간 활성 사용자(daily active user)가 뭔가요?”처럼 세부 해석이 다 달라요.
text_zh: 有正确的指标很重要，但你知道吗，很多时候大家手里有数据，但就是没有好好去追踪。产品的数据埋点(instrument)做得不到位，然后就开始各种争论。明明说的是同一个指标，但每个人理解的都不一样，比如"日活用户到底怎么定义？"这种问题就出来了。
text_es: Tener las métricas correctas es importante, pero es increíble la cantidad de veces que la gente tiene las métricas pero no las implementa bien. Se la pasan en debates interminables porque el producto no está instrumentado como debe ser. Y todos hablan de la misma métrica, pero cada quien le da su propia interpretación: "¿Qué significa realmente esto? ¿Qué es un usuario activo diario?"
context: Manik is explaining his 'consumer stack' - five capabilities companies need to build successful consumer products. He's discussing the third capability around having the right metrics and instrumentation. He emphasizes that companies often define metrics but fail to properly instrument them, leading to confusion and debates about what metrics actually mean when they're not clearly codified.
vocabulary_highlights: instrument them

speaker: Marc Benioff
speaker_expertise: B2B SaaS, AI/ML Products, Growth Strategy
text: I'm throwing everything against the wall. I'm looking at what's going to stick. I am looking to try to find the winning tactic and turn it into a winning strategy.
text_ko: 일단 닥치는 대로 다 해보고 있어요. 뭐가 먹히는지 보고, 먹히는 전술(tactic)을 찾아 그걸 효과적인 전략(strategy)으로 만들려고 해요.
text_zh: 我现在什么方法都在试，看看哪个能行。我要找到那个管用的打法，然后把它变成制胜策略。
text_es: Estoy probando de todo a ver qué funciona. Quiero ver qué da resultado. Busco encontrar la táctica ganadora y convertirla en una estrategia exitosa.
context: Lenny asks Marc about lessons from Salesforce's legendary launch event where they hired fake protesters outside a competitor's conference. Marc explains his approach to marketing and product launches, emphasizing the importance of experimentation. He describes how he tests multiple approaches simultaneously to discover what resonates with customers before committing resources to scale the most effective tactics into comprehensive strategies.
vocabulary_highlights: throwing everything against the wall, what's going to stick, winning tactic

speaker: Marc Benioff
speaker_expertise: B2B SaaS, AI/ML Products, Growth Strategy
text: I actually never look at the stock. I find the stock to be very distracting. The stock isn't the goal. That's not why we're doing this.
text_ko: 사실 저는 주식(stock)을 아예 안 봐요. 주식은 오히려 산만해서 집중을 흐트러뜨려요. 주식 자체가 목표가 아니에요. 우리가 이걸 하는 이유가 그게 아니거든요.
text_zh: 其实我从来不看股价。我觉得股价特别容易让人分心。股价不是我们的目标，我们做这个事儿也不是为了股价。
text_es: La verdad es que nunca me fijo en las acciones. Me parece que las acciones te distraen mucho. Las acciones no son el objetivo. No es por eso que estamos haciendo esto.
context: When Lenny mentions that Salesforce's stock is at an all-time high and asks what contributed to their continued growth, Marc reveals his philosophy about focusing on the business rather than financial metrics. He explains that he deliberately avoids monitoring stock prices because he believes the stock price should be a byproduct of building a great company, not the primary objective that drives decision-making.

speaker: Marc Benioff
speaker_expertise: B2B SaaS, AI/ML Products, Growth Strategy
text: No, no, no, no, no. That's a mistake. You want the mindset of, 'Oh, the next thing is coming. I can't wait for the next thing.'
text_ko: 아니요, 아니요, 아니요, 아니요, 아니요. 그건 잘못된 생각이에요. 원하시는 건 "아, 다음 일이 곧 올 거야. 다음 게 너무 기대돼서 기다릴 수가 없어"라는 마인드셋(mindset)이에요.
text_zh: 不不不，这样想就错了。你要有这种心态：'哎呀，下一个机会要来了，我都等不及了。'
text_es: No, no, no, no, no. Eso es un error. Lo que necesitas es la mentalidad de "Ay, ya viene lo siguiente. No puedo esperar a ver qué sigue."
context: Lenny expresses frustration about how founders struggle to keep up with rapid technological changes, saying they just got used to AI and now have to figure out agents. Marc strongly disagrees with this mindset, arguing that successful entrepreneurs should be excited about constant innovation rather than overwhelmed by it. He believes embracing continuous change and looking forward to new technological developments is essential for long-term success.
vocabulary_highlights: I can't wait for

speaker: Marc Benioff
speaker_expertise: B2B SaaS, AI/ML Products, Growth Strategy
text: In the beginner's mind, I have every possibility, but in the expert's mind, I have few, and in some cases, maybe none. So I've been doing this a long time. I've been writing software since I'm 15. I'm now 60. That's 45 years. I don't want to have an expert's mind. I want to have a beginner's mind.
text_ko: 초심자 마음(beginner's mind)일 때는 모든 가능성이 열려 있어요. 하지만 전문가의 마음(expert's mind)으로는 가능성이 훨씬 줄고, 어떤 경우에는 아예 없을 수도 있어요. 저는 이 일을 오래 해왔어요. 15살 때부터 소프트웨어(software)를 개발해왔고, 지금은 60살이에요. 그러니까 45년이나 됐죠. 그래서 전문가의 마음을 갖고 싶지 않아요. 계속 초심자 마음을 유지하고 싶어요.
text_zh: 初学者的心态里，什么都有可能，但专家的心态里，可能性就很少了，有时候甚至完全没有。我做这行已经很久了，从15岁就开始写代码，现在60岁了，整整45年。我不想有专家心态，我要保持初学者心态。
text_es: Con la mentalidad de principiante, tengo todas las posibilidades del mundo, pero con la mentalidad de experto, tengo pocas, y en algunos casos, tal vez ninguna. Mira, llevo mucho tiempo en esto. He estado programando desde los 15 años. Ahora tengo 60. Son 45 años. No quiero tener mentalidad de experto. Quiero mantener la mentalidad de principiante.
context: Marc discusses the importance of maintaining a beginner's mind even after decades of experience. He explains this concept from Zen Buddhism called 'Shoshin' - the idea that approaching situations with an open, eager attitude free from preconceptions leads to more creative solutions. Despite 45 years in software development, he actively cultivates this mindset through meditation and deliberately avoiding the trap of thinking he knows all the answers.
vocabulary_highlights: beginner's mind, expert's mind

speaker: Marc Benioff
speaker_expertise: B2B SaaS, AI/ML Products, Growth Strategy
text: I am looking to try to find the winning tactic and turn it into a winning strategy. I don't know actually which one of those things is going to be the most important thing in launching this product, so I'm trying a lot of things with that old expression. I'm throwing everything against the wall. I'm looking at what's going to stick.
text_ko: 효과 있는 전술(winning tactic)을 찾아서 그걸 효과적인 전략(winning strategy)으로 만들려고 해요. 사실 어떤 게 이 제품 출시에서 가장 중요할지 모르겠어서, 옛말처럼 이것저것 많이 시도해 보고 있어요. 가능한 건 다 해봐서 뭐가 통하는지 보고 있어요.
text_zh: 我想找到那个制胜的策略，把它变成一套完整的打法。说实话，我也不知道在推这个产品的时候哪个点最关键，所以我就多试试呗，就是那句老话说的——广撒网，看看哪个能行得通。
text_es: Estoy buscando encontrar la táctica que funcione y convertirla en una estrategia ganadora. La verdad es que no sé cuál de todas estas cosas va a ser lo más importante para lanzar este producto, así que estoy probando muchas cosas con esa filosofía de siempre. Estoy echando toda la carne al asador. Quiero ver qué es lo que va a cuajar.
context: Marc explains his current approach to launching Agentforce, Salesforce's new AI agent product. He describes running multiple parallel experiments including celebrity endorsements with Matthew McConaughey and Woody Harrelson, aggressive marketing against Microsoft's Copilot, and hiring additional salespeople. His philosophy is to test many different tactics simultaneously rather than betting everything on one approach, then scale whichever proves most effective.
vocabulary_highlights: throwing everything against the wall, what's going to stick, winning tactic
topics: Growth & Marketing, Product Management, Strategy & Planning

speaker: Marc Benioff
speaker_expertise: B2B SaaS, AI/ML Products, Growth Strategy
text: It's not just about the product. It's not just about sales. It's not just about marketing. It's about everything, so you better be ready to be an orchestra leader. You can't just be playing the clarinet.
text_ko: 제품만으로 되는 게 아니에요. 영업만으로 되는 것도 아니고, 마케팅만으로 되는 것도 아니에요. 결국 모든 걸 아우르는 일이어서 오케스트라 지휘자(orchestra leader)처럼 전체를 지휘할 준비가 돼 있어야 해요. 클라리넷만 불고 있으면 안 돼요.
text_zh: 这不只是产品的事儿，也不只是销售的事儿，更不只是市场营销的事儿。这是个全方位的活儿，所以你得准备好当个乐队指挥。你不能只会吹单簧管就完事了。
text_es: No es solo el producto. No es solo las ventas. No es solo el marketing. Es todo junto, así que más te vale estar listo para ser director de orquesta. No puedes quedarte solo tocando el clarinete.
context: Lenny asks about advice for product-oriented founders who are hesitant to focus on sales and marketing. Marc responds by rejecting the idea that companies should be narrowly focused on just one area like product development. He uses the metaphor of an orchestra to explain that successful entrepreneurs must coordinate all aspects of their business - product, sales, marketing, finance, employees, and stakeholders - rather than excelling in just one area.
vocabulary_highlights: orchestra leader, playing the clarinet

speaker: Marc Benioff
speaker_expertise: B2B SaaS, AI/ML Products, Growth Strategy
text: My friend, Michael Bell, is probably the best entrepreneur I know. He says, 'There is no linear success.' So what that means is that stock chart that you just referred to, there's no up-and-to-the-right perfect chart where it's just one line.
text_ko: 제 친구 마이클 벨은 아마 제가 아는 최고의 기업가예요. 그는 "성공에는 선형적(linear success)인 경로가 없다"고 말해요. 그러니까 방금 말씀하신 그 주식 차트(stock chart)는 한 줄로 쭉 이어져서 계속 우상향(up-and-to-the-right)만 하는 완벽한 그래프는 없다는 뜻이에요.
text_zh: 我朋友迈克尔·贝尔，应该是我认识的最厉害的创业者了。他总说，"成功这事儿没有直线型的。" 意思就是你刚才提到的那个股票图表，不可能是一条完美的从左下到右上的直线，现实中根本没有这种一帆风顺的曲线。
text_es: Mi amigo Michael Bell es probablemente el mejor emprendedor que conozco. Él siempre dice: "No existe el éxito lineal". O sea, esa gráfica bursátil de la que acabas de hablar, no hay ninguna curva perfecta que vaya siempre para arriba y a la derecha, como una sola línea recta.
context: Marc shares a difficult period from two years ago when Salesforce had to lay off 10% of their workforce after overhiring during the pandemic. He reflects on this failure and the broader lesson that entrepreneurship involves constant ups and downs. He quotes entrepreneur Michael Bell's wisdom that no company, not even Apple, experiences perfectly smooth growth - there will always be setbacks, economic changes, and unexpected challenges.
vocabulary_highlights: linear success, up-and-to-the-right

speaker: Marily Nika
speaker_expertise: Product Management, Product Design, AI/ML Products
text: There is something called the shiny object trap, and I'm always telling people, 'Hey, don't do AI for the sake of doing AI.' Make sure there is a problem there. Make sure there is a pain point that needs to be solved in a smart way. Once you have identified what that problem is and what that very, very high-level solution is, then reach out and try to figure out how to actually implement it.
text_ko: 샤이니 오브젝트 트랩(shiny object trap)이라는 게 있는데요, 저는 항상 사람들에게 "그냥 한다고 해서 AI를 도입하지 마세요"라고 말해요. 실제로 해결해야 할 문제가 있는지, 그리고 똑똑하게 해결해야 할 페인 포인트(pain point)가 있는지 꼭 확인하세요. 그 문제와 아주 높은 수준의 해결책(high-level solution)이 무엇인지 파악한 다음에는, 실제로 어떻게 구현할지 찾아보고 시도해 보세요.
text_zh: 有个东西叫"闪亮物体陷阱"(shiny object trap)，我总是跟大家说，"嘿，别为了做AI而做AI。"你得确保那里真的有问题存在，确保有个痛点需要用巧妙的方式来解决。一旦你搞清楚问题是什么，以及大方向的解决方案是什么，然后再去琢磨具体怎么落地实施。
text_es: Existe algo que se llama la trampa del objeto brillante (shiny object trap), y siempre les digo a las empresas: "Oigan, no hagan IA solo por hacer IA." Asegúrense de que realmente haya un problema ahí. Asegúrense de que exista un punto de dolor (pain point) que necesite resolverse de manera inteligente. Una vez que hayan identificado cuál es ese problema y cuál es esa solución a muy alto nivel, entonces sí, acérquense y traten de encontrar cómo implementarla realmente.
context: Lenny asks Marily about when AI might not be a good approach to solving problems, given that many AI investments end up being low ROI and taking months to show results. The 'shiny object trap' refers to the tendency to pursue trendy technologies without clear purpose. Marily emphasizes that product managers should always start by identifying genuine user problems and pain points before considering AI solutions, rather than implementing AI technology just because it's exciting or fashionable.
vocabulary_highlights: shiny object trap, pain point, high-level solution, reach out
topics: Product Management, Strategy & Planning, Decision Making

speaker: Marily Nika
speaker_expertise: Product Management, Product Design, AI/ML Products
text: I believe that all product managers will be AI product managers in the future. And this is because we see all products needing to have a personalized experience, a recommender system that is actually good. I mean you cannot watch Netflix, you cannot even watch a movie without needing that. After you watch White Lotus or Stranger Things, you will want something similar to watch. You're not going to want a romantic thing to be suggested or recommended to you.
text_ko: 앞으로 모든 프로덕트 매니저들이 AI 프로덕트 매니저(AI product managers)가 될 거라고 생각해요. 그 이유는 모든 제품이 개인화된 경험(personalized experience)을 제공해야 하고, 정말 잘 작동하는 추천 시스템(recommender system)이 필요해지는 걸 보았기 때문이에요. 제 말은 넷플릭스 같은 서비스를 볼 때 그게 없으면 영화를 보기 힘들어요. 'White Lotus'나 'Stranger Things'를 본 뒤에는 비슷한 걸 보고 싶을 텐데, 로맨스물이 추천되는 걸 원하지 않잖아요.
text_zh: 我觉得以后所有的产品经理都会变成AI产品经理。为什么这么说呢？因为现在所有产品都需要个性化体验，需要一个真正好用的推荐系统(recommender system)。就拿看Netflix来说吧，现在你想看个电影都离不开推荐算法。比如你刚看完《白莲花度假村》或者《怪奇物语》，肯定想看点类似的内容对吧？这时候系统要是给你推荐爱情片，你肯定不乐意啊。
text_es: Creo que todos los product managers van a ser product managers de IA en el futuro. Y esto es porque vemos que todos los productos necesitan tener una experiencia personalizada, un sistema de recomendaciones que realmente funcione bien. O sea, no puedes ver Netflix, ni siquiera puedes ver una película sin necesitar eso. Después de que veas White Lotus o Stranger Things, vas a querer ver algo parecido. No vas a querer que te sugieran o recomienden algo romántico.
context: Lenny asks Marily what she means when she says AI will be the default in the future. Marily explains her vision that every product manager will eventually become an AI product manager because all modern products require personalization, recommendations, and automation to meet user expectations. She uses Netflix's recommendation system as an example of how AI has become essential for delivering relevant, personalized experiences that users now expect as standard.
vocabulary_highlights: recommender system, personalized experience

speaker: Marily Nika
speaker_expertise: Product Management, Product Design, AI/ML Products
text: Don't do it for your MVP. It makes zero sense. Do not waste time of data scientists that can train models using powerful machines that are going take weeks to train. This is because if you have an MVP and you just want to get buy-in for an idea or feature that may use AI in the future, fake it, create a little Figma prototype and just show it to some users, just fake what the AI is going to be doing.
text_ko: MVP를 위해 그렇게 하지 마세요. 전혀 의미가 없어요. 강력한 머신을 이용해 모델을 훈련할 수 있는 데이터 과학자들의 시간을 낭비하지 마세요. 훈련하는 데 몇 주가 걸릴 수 있거든요. 만약 MVP가 있고, 단순히 아이디어나 기능에 대한 동의를 얻고 싶다면, 그냥 Figma 프로토타입 같은 걸 만들어서 몇몇 사용자에게 보여주면 돼요. AI가 할 것처럼 보이게 살짝 꾸며서 보여주는 거죠.
text_zh: MVP阶段千万别这么干，完全没意义。别浪费数据科学家的时间让他们用高配机器训练模型，那种训练一跑就是好几周。因为如果你只是做MVP，就是想让大家认可一个想法或者功能，以后可能会用到AI，那就直接造假呗，做个Figma原型出来给用户看看，把AI要做的事情模拟一下就行了。
text_es: No lo hagas para tu MVP. No tiene ningún sentido. No desperdicies el tiempo de los científicos de datos que pueden entrenar modelos usando máquinas potentes que van a tardar semanas en entrenar. Esto es porque si tienes un MVP y solo quieres conseguir apoyo para una idea o funcionalidad que tal vez use IA en el futuro, simúlalo, crea un prototipito en Figma y simplemente muéstraselo a algunos usuarios, solo simula lo que va a hacer la IA.
context: Lenny asks about signs that AI may not be a good approach to solving problems. Marily strongly advises against using AI for minimum viable products (MVPs). An MVP is the simplest version of a product used to test market demand and gather early feedback. Instead of spending weeks training expensive models for unproven concepts, she recommends creating mock-ups in design tools like Figma to simulate AI functionality and validate user interest before investing in actual AI development.
vocabulary_highlights: MVP, get buy-in, fake it, mock-ups
topics: Product Management, Strategy & Planning, Starting a Company

speaker: Marily Nika
speaker_expertise: Product Management, Product Design, AI/ML Products
text: So I have a three-year-old girl and I'm teaching her about life and everything. So I was recently teaching her about the animals and you explain things to her once or twice, what a mammal is or rhino and so on. But you will end up training your kid's brain by repeating the same information again. So you will say, 'Hey, here's what the rhino looks like, here's what an elephant looks like,' and once you've done this enough times, then your kid will see an animal on the street and they'll be able to recognize and say, 'Oh yeah, that's like rhino we're talking about.' This is exactly what a model is.
text_ko: 제가 세 살 된 딸이 있어요. 그 아이한테 삶과 이런저런 걸 가르치고 있는데요, 얼마 전엔 동물에 대해 알려주고 있었어요. 포유류가 뭔지, 코뿔소가 어떤 동물인지 한두 번 설명해 주면 되는데요, 같은 정보를 반복해서 알려주다 보면 결국 아이의 뇌를 훈련시키게 돼요. 예를 들어 '코뿔소는 이렇게 생겼고, 코끼리는 이렇게 생겼어' 하고 자꾸 보여주면, 나중에 길에서 동물을 보면 '아, 아까 말한 코뿔소랑 비슷하네' 하고 알아보게 되는 거예요. 이게 바로 모델(model)이에요.
text_zh: 我有个三岁的女儿，平时教她认识这个世界的各种东西。最近在教她认动物，你跟她解释一两遍什么是哺乳动物啊、犀牛长什么样啊这些。但是你得不断重复同样的信息，这样才能训练孩子的大脑。你会说"来，犀牛长这样，大象长那样"，重复多了以后，你孩子在街上看到动物就能认出来，会说"哎呀，这就是我们说的那个犀牛！"这就是模型(model)的工作原理。
text_es: Mira, tengo una niña de tres años y le estoy enseñando sobre la vida y todo eso. Hace poco le estaba enseñando sobre los animales y le explicas las cosas una o dos veces, qué es un mamífero o un rinoceronte y todo eso. Pero terminas entrenando el cerebro de tu hijo repitiendo la misma información una y otra vez. Entonces le dices: "Mira, así se ve un rinoceronte, así se ve un elefante", y una vez que has hecho esto suficientes veces, entonces tu hijo ve un animal en la calle y puede reconocerlo y decir: "Ah sí, eso es como el rinoceronte del que estábamos hablando". Esto es exactamente lo que es un modelo.
context: Lenny asks Marily to explain what a model is for non-technical people. Marily uses the analogy of teaching her three-year-old daughter to recognize animals. Just as a child learns to identify animals by seeing many examples repeatedly, an AI model learns patterns from training data. The model becomes like a trained brain that can take new inputs (like images) and recognize what they contain based on the patterns it learned during training.
vocabulary_highlights: training your kid's brain, repeating the same information

speaker: Marily Nika
speaker_expertise: Product Management, Product Design, AI/ML Products
text: I'd like to see people being less overwhelmed, less intimidated, less afraid to start learning how to code, how to train a little model on their own. This is because even if ChatGPT or these no-code applications may be able to do this for us, it gives you a different approach, a different mindset, a different confidence to know how things work.
text_ko: 사람들이 코딩(coding)을 배우기 시작할 때 덜 압도당하고, 덜 위축되고, 덜 두려워했으면 해요. 자신이 직접 작은 모델을 훈련시키는 법(train a little model on their own)도 마찬가지예요. 설령 ChatGPT(ChatGPT)나 이런 노코드 애플리케이션(no-code applications)이 우리 대신 해줄 수 있다 해도, 스스로 어떻게 작동하는지 아는 건 다른 접근 방식과 다른 사고방식, 그리고 자신감을 줘요.
text_zh: 我希望大家不要被编程吓到，不要觉得压力山大，也别害怕开始学写代码，或者自己训练个小模型什么的。虽然ChatGPT或者那些无代码(no-code)工具可能都能帮我们搞定这些事儿，但你自己会了就不一样了，思维方式会变，做事的信心也会不同，因为你知道这些东西到底是怎么运作的。
text_es: Me gustaría ver que la gente se sienta menos abrumada, menos intimidada, que tenga menos miedo de empezar a aprender a programar o a entrenar un pequeño modelo por su cuenta. Esto es porque aunque ChatGPT o estas aplicaciones sin código (no-code) puedan hacerlo por nosotros, te da un enfoque diferente, una mentalidad distinta, otra confianza al saber cómo funcionan las cosas por dentro.
context: Lenny asks whether there are areas PMs should invest in skill-wise as AI becomes more prevalent. Marily encourages product managers to overcome their fear of learning to code and train basic models themselves. She compares this to learning piano fundamentals - even if tools can automate tasks, understanding the underlying mechanics gives you better intuition, confidence, and strategic thinking when making product decisions involving AI technology.
vocabulary_highlights: less intimidated, no-code applications, different mindset

speaker: Marily Nika
speaker_expertise: Product Management, Product Design, AI/ML Products
text: What I feel people should understand is what it takes to manage an AI product. Of course people are very familiar with the stages of product development in general, but AI product development is different. As I mentioned before, sometimes you're actually managing the problem and not the product and you're trying to scope out if there is a problem that makes sense to be answered by a smart solution.
text_ko: 제가 사람들이 알았으면 하는 건 AI 제품(AI product)을 관리하려면 어떤 일이 필요한지예요. 물론 일반적인 제품 개발(product development) 단계는 익숙하실 텐데, AI 제품 개발은 달라요. 앞서 말했듯이 때로는 제품 자체를 관리하는 게 아니라 문제를 관리하게 되고, 그 문제가 스마트한 솔루션(smart solution)으로 의미 있게 답할 수 있는지 범위를 정하는(스코핑(scoping)) 작업을 하게 돼요.
text_zh: 我觉得大家应该明白的是，管理AI产品到底需要什么。当然了，大家对一般的产品开发流程都很熟悉，但AI产品开发就不一样了。就像我之前说的，有时候你其实是在管理问题本身，而不是管理产品，你要搞清楚这个问题是不是真的需要用智能化的方案来解决。
text_es: Lo que creo que la gente debería entender es lo que implica gestionar un producto de IA. Claro, todos conocemos bien las etapas del desarrollo de productos en general, pero el desarrollo de productos de IA es otra cosa. Como mencioné antes, a veces en realidad estás gestionando el problema y no el producto, y estás tratando de definir si hay un problema que tenga sentido resolver con una solución inteligente.
context: Lenny asks what PMs should do to become strong AI product managers. Marily explains that AI product management requires different skills than traditional product management. Unlike regular products where you manage features and roadmaps, AI product management often involves 'managing the problem' - determining whether a problem even exists that warrants an AI solution, and whether that problem can be effectively solved with available data and technology.
vocabulary_highlights: scope out, makes sense to be answered, smart solution

speaker: Marily Nika
speaker_expertise: Product Management, Product Design, AI/ML Products
text: You may have been working on all of these incredible research and ideas and hypotheses, but then when you actually train the model, the results you may be getting may not be optimal, may not be answering the questions or the hypothesis that you actually had in mind. So that's number one. You need to be able to encourage the teams throughout this process because you're like the captain of the ship, you need to be the one that's cheerleading the team, making sure everyone keeps going.
text_ko: 멋진 연구와 아이디어, 여러 가설들(hypotheses)을 쌓아왔을 수 있어요. 그런데 실제로 모델을 학습시켜볼 때(train the model)는 기대만큼 성과가 안 나거나, 원래 의도했던 질문이나 가설에 답하지 못하는 경우가 있어요. 이게 첫 번째로 짚어야 할 점이에요. 그리고 이 과정 전체에서 팀을 계속 격려해야 해요. 당신은 배의 선장 같은 위치라서 팀의 치어리더 역할(cheerleading)을 하면서 모두가 멈추지 않고 계속 나아가도록 챙겨야 해요.
text_zh: 你可能已经做了很多很棒的研究，有很多想法和假设，但是等你真正开始训练模型的时候，得出来的结果可能不太理想，可能根本回答不了你原本想解决的问题，或者验证不了你的假设。这是第一点。在这整个过程中，你得给团队打气加油，因为你就像船长一样，你得当啦啦队长，确保大家都能坚持下去。
text_es: Puede que hayas estado trabajando en todas estas investigaciones increíbles, ideas e hipótesis, pero luego cuando realmente entrenas el modelo, los resultados que obtienes pueden no ser los óptimos, pueden no estar respondiendo las preguntas o la hipótesis que tenías en mente. Entonces ese es el punto número uno. Tienes que poder motivar a los equipos durante todo este proceso porque eres como el capitán del barco, tienes que ser el que anime al equipo, asegurándote de que todos sigan adelante.
context: Lenny asks what else Marily wants to share from her course about AI product management. Marily discusses the key challenges of being an AI PM, particularly dealing with uncertainty when research doesn't produce expected results. Unlike traditional product development with predictable outcomes, AI projects often fail to meet initial hypotheses even after months of work. She emphasizes that AI PMs must act as team motivators and leaders during these uncertain periods.
vocabulary_highlights: may not be optimal, captain of the ship, cheerleading the team

speaker: Marty Cagan
text: There is no question that a lot of companies overhired during the pandemic. I go into some companies and honestly I can't believe all the ridiculous roles that they have, agile coaches and product owners and product ops and business analysts.
text_ko: 팬데믹 때 많은 회사가 채용을 과하게 한 건 분명해요. 몇몇 회사에 가 보면 솔직히 애자일 코치(agile coach), 프로덕트 오너(product owner), 프로덕트 운영(product ops), 비즈니스 애널리스트(business analyst) 같은 어처구니없는 직책들이 있는 걸 보고는 믿을 수가 없어요.
text_zh: 毫无疑问，疫情期间很多公司确实招人招得太猛了。我去一些公司看，说实话真是被他们那些莫名其妙的岗位给震惊了，什么敏捷教练(agile coach)啊、产品负责人(product owner)啊、产品运营(product ops)啊、业务分析师(business analyst)啊，一大堆。
text_es: No hay duda de que muchas empresas contrataron de más durante la pandemia. Entro a algunas empresas y la verdad no me puedo creer todos los puestos absurdos que tienen: coaches ágiles, product owners, product ops, analistas de negocio...
context: Lenny asks about the spiciness in Marty's recent writing, leading to a discussion about factors causing chaos in the product community. Marty explains that companies not only overhired during the pandemic but also lowered hiring standards, creating numerous unnecessary roles. He argues that many companies have created positions that don't add meaningful value compared to how the best product companies operate with leaner, more focused teams.
vocabulary_highlights: ridiculous roles, overhired

speaker: Marty Cagan
text: They're dramatically overpaid for the value they provide. Because it's a project management role. It is a lot easier to deliver output than it is to deliver outcomes.
text_ko: 그들은 제공하는 가치에 비해 보수를 지나치게 많이 받고 있어요. 그건 프로젝트 관리 역할(project management role)이기 때문이에요. 산출물(output)을 내는 건 결과(outcome)를 만들어내는 것보다 훨씬 쉬워요.
text_zh: 他们拿的薪水跟他们创造的价值完全不成正比，拿得太多了。因为这就是个项目管理(project management)的活儿嘛。你要说交付成果(output)，那简单，但要真正实现效果(outcomes)，那就难多了。
text_es: Están súper sobrepagados para el valor que realmente aportan. Porque es un puesto de gestión de proyectos. Es mucho más fácil entregar productos que entregar resultados de verdad.
context: Lenny describes Marty's concept of 'product management theater' - people who aren't real product managers but hold the title. Marty explains that many people calling themselves product managers are actually doing project management work, focusing on shipping features rather than solving problems. He emphasizes the critical difference between delivering output (shipping features) versus delivering outcomes (solving customer and business problems).
vocabulary_highlights: dramatically overpaid, deliver output, deliver outcomes

speaker: Marty Cagan
text: Too many people in our industry view themselves as a victim of their company, like they're stuck in a feature team and there's nothing they can do about it other than quit. I think that's not true. There is so much they can do.
text_ko: 우리 업계에서는 스스로를 회사의 피해자라고 보는 분들이 너무 많아요. 마치 기능팀(feature team)에 갇혀서 그걸 벗어날 방법은 그만두는 것뿐이라고 생각하죠. 저는 그게 사실이 아니라고 봐요. 할 수 있는 일이 정말 많아요.
text_zh: 我们这个行业里太多人都觉得自己是公司的受害者，好像被困在功能团队(feature team)里就没办法了，除了辞职别无选择。我觉得这想法不对，其实他们能做的事情多着呢。
text_es: Mucha gente en nuestra industria se ve como víctima de su empresa, como si estuviera atrapada en un equipo de desarrollo y no pudiera hacer nada más que renunciar. Yo creo que eso no es cierto. Hay muchísimo que pueden hacer.
context: Lenny asks what motivated Marty to write his third book, TRANSFORMED. Marty explains that many product professionals feel trapped in organizations that operate as 'feature teams' - teams given roadmaps of features to build rather than problems to solve. Instead of viewing themselves as powerless victims, Marty argues these individuals have much more agency than they realize to transform their companies and elevate their own roles.
vocabulary_highlights: view themselves as a victim, stuck in a feature team

speaker: Marty Cagan
text: We are looking for the commonality and mostly we're looking to help a company, whether it's a startup or a large company to have the best possible chance of success. That's the goal for us. It's a different goal.
text_ko: 우리는 공통점을 찾고, 무엇보다 스타트업이든 대기업이든 회사가 성공할 가능성을 최대한 높일 수 있도록 돕는 데 집중하고 있어요. 그게 우리의 목표예요. 좀 다른 목표예요.
text_zh: 我们主要是在找共同点，更重要的是，我们想帮助公司——不管是初创公司(startup)还是大企业——让他们有最大的成功机会。这就是我们的目标，跟别人不太一样。
text_es: Buscamos los puntos en común y sobre todo queremos ayudar a una empresa, ya sea una startup o una compañía grande, a que tenga las mejores posibilidades de éxito. Ese es nuestro objetivo. Es un enfoque distinto.
context: Marty contrasts his approach with Lenny's podcast style. While Lenny seeks to showcase diverse perspectives and unique practices across different companies, Marty explains that his Silicon Valley Product Group focuses on identifying common principles and practices consistently used by the best product companies. Their heuristic requires seeing techniques used successfully by multiple proven companies before they evangelize them.
vocabulary_highlights: looking for the commonality, best possible chance of success

speaker: Marty Cagan
text: I do. In fact, I've got some very uncomfortable things to talk about, which I know the more intelligent part of me is like, "Don't bring that up." But also the other side of me is like, "But people need to hear it."
text_ko: 네, 있어요. 사실 꽤 불편한 얘기들이 있어요. 머리로는 '그 얘기 꺼내지 마'라고 하는데, 다른 한쪽은 '그래도 사람들이 들어야 해'라고 해요.
text_zh: 有啊。其实我有些挺敏感的话题想聊，我理智的那一面告诉我"别提这事儿"，但另一面又觉得"大家确实需要听听这些"。
text_es: Claro que sí. De hecho, tengo que hablar de algunas cosas bastante incómodas, y sé que la parte más inteligente de mí me dice "No saques ese tema." Pero por otro lado también pienso "La gente necesita escuchar esto."
context: Lenny asks about Marty's recent 'spiciness' in writing, suggesting he's telling people things they don't want to hear but need to hear. Marty confirms this is conscious - he's deliberately dialing up his rhetoric around uncomfortable truths in the product management industry. He acknowledges internal conflict between staying diplomatic versus sharing harsh realities that could help people and companies improve.
vocabulary_highlights: uncomfortable things, the more intelligent part of me

speaker: Marty Cagan
text: And then the one that I really probably shouldn't bring up just because it's become a religious topic almost. I know it's a super sensitive topic for people, but the reality is with remote employees, both velocity and innovation have taken a real hit.
text_ko: 솔직히 이 얘기는 거의 종교 논쟁 수준이라서 꺼내지 않는 게 나을 수도 있는데요. 사람들한테 정말 민감한 주제인 건 알고요. 그런데 현실은 원격 근무자의 경우 속도(velocity)와 혁신(innovation) 둘 다 실질적으로 큰 타격을 받았어요.
text_zh: 还有一个我本来不太想提的话题，因为这几乎成了一个很敏感的宗教话题了。我知道大家对这个都很敏感，但现实就是远程办公的员工，无论是工作效率还是创新能力，确实都受到了不小的冲击。
text_es: Y luego está el tema que probablemente no debería ni mencionar porque se ha vuelto casi como una religión. Sé que es un tema súper delicado para la gente, pero la realidad es que con los empleados remotos, tanto la velocidad como la innovación han sufrido un golpe bastante duro.
context: Marty discusses macro factors creating challenges in the product management field, including overhiring during the pandemic, rising cost of funds, and potential AI disruption. He addresses what he calls a 'religious topic' - the impact of remote work on product development. Despite knowing it's sensitive, he shares his observation that companies with remote teams struggle with both development speed and innovation compared to co-located teams.
vocabulary_highlights: religious topic, super sensitive topic, taken a real hit

speaker: Marty Cagan
text: People don't buy the problem, they buy your solution. Obviously they don't buy it if it's not solving something they care about, but there are many products that are solving what they care about. The real question is, do you solve it better than everybody else so that they buy you? And that's where you need to take time.
text_ko: 사람들은 문제 자체를 사는 게 아니라, 그 문제를 해결해 주는 여러분의 솔루션(solution)을 사요. 물론 그들이 중요하게 여기는 문제를 해결하지 못하면 사지 않아요. 그런데 그들이 신경 쓰는 문제를 해결해 주는 제품(product)은 많아요. 진짜 질문은, 다른 경쟁자보다 더 잘 해결해서 사람들이 여러분의 솔루션(solution)을 선택하게 만들 수 있느냐는 거예요. 그걸 위해 시간을 투자해야 해요.
text_zh: 客户买的不是问题本身，而是你的解决方案。当然了，如果你解决的不是他们关心的事情，那肯定不会买单。但是市面上解决同样问题的产品一大堆。真正的关键是，你能不能比其他人做得更好，让客户选择你？这就需要你花时间好好琢磨了。
text_es: La gente no compra el problema, compra tu solución. Obvio que no la van a comprar si no está resolviendo algo que les importa, pero hay muchos productos que sí resuelven lo que les importa. La pregunta de verdad es: ¿lo resuelves mejor que todos los demás para que te elijan a ti? Y ahí es donde tienes que invertir tiempo.
context: Lenny is asking about product discovery and how teams should spend their time between understanding problems versus creating solutions. Marty is explaining why product teams should focus most of their discovery time on solution development rather than problem validation. He argues that while problems are important, customers ultimately purchase solutions, and the key differentiator is building a better solution than competitors.

speaker: Marty Cagan
text: It's frustrating because I really thought by the year 2022, we would not have such a chasm between how good companies work and the rest. There's such strong incentives, just the profit motive alone. Why don't more companies want to work like the best? So I find that just perplexing.
text_ko: 정말 2022년쯤이면 잘하는 회사들이 일하는 방식과 다른 회사들 사이에 이런 큰 격차가 없을 줄 알았어요. 유인이 충분히 강한데, 이윤 동기(profit motive)만 봐도 그렇고요. 그래서 왜 더 많은 회사들이 최고 수준처럼 일하려고 하지 않는지 정말 이해가 안 돼요.
text_zh: 这真的很让人郁闷，我原本以为到了2022年，优秀公司和普通公司之间不会有这么大的差距。动力其实很强啊，光是利润驱动就够了。为什么更多公司不愿意学习那些最好的公司呢？我觉得这事儿真的很费解。
text_es: Es frustrante porque realmente pensé que para el año 2022, no tendríamos semejante abismo entre cómo funcionan las empresas que lo hacen bien y el resto. Hay incentivos muy fuertes, solo el motivo de ganancia ya es suficiente. ¿Por qué no quieren más empresas trabajar como las mejores? Eso me resulta desconcertante.
context: Lenny asks Marty about his recent philosophical approach to writing about product management and the misconceptions he's been observing. Marty explains his frustration with the persistent gap between high-performing product companies and the majority of companies. Despite clear financial incentives and proven success models, most companies continue using outdated product development approaches rather than adopting the practices of leading tech companies.
vocabulary_highlights: chasm, profit motive alone, perplexing

speaker: Marty Cagan
text: In a feature team, basically you are handed a typical roadmap. Almost everybody, even though I wish this wasn't the case, almost everybody to have the same thing, that it's a prioritized list of features and projects. So some stakeholders got together, usually quarterly, and they say, 'Look, to run our part of the business, we need these features.'
text_ko: 기능 팀(feature team)에서는 보통 전형적인 로드맵을 넘겨받아요. 솔직히 이게 아니었으면 좋겠지만, 거의 다들 똑같아요 — 우선순위가 매겨진 기능과 프로젝트 목록(features and projects)을요. 그래서 이해관계자들이 보통 분기마다 모여서, "우리 쪽 비즈니스를 운영하려면 이 기능들이 필요하다"고 말해요.
text_zh: 在功能团队(feature team)里，基本上就是给你一个典型的路线图(roadmap)。几乎所有人，虽然我希望情况不是这样，但几乎所有人拿到的都是同一个东西——就是一个按优先级排列的功能和项目清单。一般是一些利益相关方(stakeholders)聚在一起，通常是每个季度一次，然后他们会说："你看，要想把我们这块业务搞好，我们需要这些功能。"
text_es: En un equipo de funcionalidades (feature team), básicamente te entregan una hoja de ruta típica. Casi todo el mundo, aunque ojalá no fuera así, casi todo el mundo tiene lo mismo: una lista priorizada de funcionalidades y proyectos. Entonces se juntan algunos stakeholders, normalmente cada trimestre, y dicen: "Mira, para manejar nuestra parte del negocio, necesitamos estas funcionalidades."
context: Lenny asks Marty to help listeners identify whether they work on a feature team (feature factory) or a real product team. Marty explains the characteristics of feature teams, where teams are given predetermined solutions in the form of roadmaps rather than problems to solve. He describes how stakeholders typically create quarterly lists of required features, essentially asking teams to build pre-defined solutions rather than empowering them to discover the best approaches.
vocabulary_highlights: prioritized list

speaker: Marty Cagan
text: But on an empowered product team, where you're trying to come up with a solution that solves the problem you've been assigned, that's much harder because that means we have to discover a solution that's valuable, usable, feasible, viable. Now while the engineers definitely own feasible, and the designer definitely owns usable, valuable and viable, which are two of the hardest things to do, that's the product manager.
text_ko: 하지만 권한이 주어진 프로덕트 팀(empowered product team)에서는 배정된 문제를 실제로 해결할 수 있는 해법을 찾아내야 해서 훨씬 더 어려워요. 우리가 찾아야 하는 해법은 가치(valuable)가 있고, 사용성(usable)이 뛰어나고, 실현 가능성(feasible)이 있으며, 사업성(viable)도 갖춰야 하거든요. 엔지니어들은 확실히 실현 가능성(feasible)을 책임지고, 디자이너는 사용성(usable)을 책임지지만, 가치(valuable)와 사업성(viable) — 이 두 가지가 가장 어려운 과제들 중 하나예요 — 을 책임지는 건 프로덕트 매니저(product manager)예요.
text_zh: 但是在一个有自主权的产品团队里，你要想出解决方案来搞定分配给你的问题，这就难多了，因为这意味着我们得找到一个既有价值、又好用、还能实现、也能盈利的解决方案。虽然工程师肯定负责"能不能实现"这块，设计师肯定负责"好不好用"这块，但是"有没有价值"和"能不能盈利"——这两个最难搞的事情，就是产品经理的活儿了。
text_es: Pero en un equipo de producto empoderado (empowered), donde estás tratando de encontrar una solución que resuelva el problema que te asignaron, eso es mucho más difícil porque significa que tenemos que descubrir una solución que sea valiosa, usable, factible y viable. Ahora, mientras que los ingenieros definitivamente se encargan de lo factible, y el diseñador se encarga de lo usable, lo valioso y lo viable, que son dos de las cosas más difíciles de lograr, eso le toca al product manager.
context: Continuing his explanation of the differences between feature teams and empowered product teams, Marty describes how empowered product teams work. Instead of building predetermined features, these teams are given problems to solve and must discover solutions that meet four key criteria. He explains how responsibilities are divided: engineers handle feasibility, designers handle usability, while product managers tackle the challenging areas of value and viability.
vocabulary_highlights: empowered product team

speaker: Marty Cagan
text: Nothing I talk about, and honestly being very clear, nothing I've written about in Inspired, nothing I've written about in Empowered was invented by us. All we do is share the practices we see being used in the best teams. So the heuristic is pretty easy. If it's used by several of the best teams, we're like, 'Okay, let's start recommending it.'
text_ko: 솔직히 말하면요, 제가 이야기하는 것들—그리고 분명히 해두자면 제가 Inspired나 Empowered에 쓴 내용들 중 어느 것도 우리가 발명한 게 아니에요. 우리가 하는 건 최고의 팀들이 실제로 쓰는 관행들만 공유하는 거예요. 그래서 판단 기준(heuristic)은 꽤 간단해요. 여러 우수한 팀들이 쓰고 있으면, '좋아요, 그럼 추천을 시작해보죠' 하는 식이에요.
text_zh: 说实话，我讲的这些东西，还有我在《启示录》和《赋能》里写的那些，都不是我们发明的。我们就是把那些顶尖团队在用的方法分享出来而已。判断标准其实很简单——如果好几个顶级团队都在用某个做法，我们就会想"行，那咱们就开始推荐这个方法吧。"
text_es: Nada de lo que hablo, y siendo muy honesto, nada de lo que he escrito en Inspired, nada de lo que he escrito en Empowered lo inventamos nosotros. Lo único que hacemos es compartir las prácticas que vemos que usan los mejores equipos. Así que la regla es bastante sencilla. Si varios de los mejores equipos lo están usando, decimos: "Bueno, empecemos a recomendarlo."
context: Lenny asks whether the high-performing product practices Marty describes actually exist at real companies, as some people doubt these methods are used anywhere. Marty explains his methodology for developing recommendations - he doesn't invent practices but rather observes and shares what the best product teams are already doing. He describes his approach of only recommending practices that are proven effective at multiple top-performing companies.
vocabulary_highlights: heuristic

speaker: Marty Cagan
text: And his argument was because as a company gets bigger, product historically became less important. The people in a company that would be celebrated were marketing people, sales people, finance people. If a company stops innovating, these are the engines for growth. Sales, marketing, or not growth with finance, but cutting cost.
text_ko: 그의 주장은, 회사가 커질수록 역사적으로 프로덕트(product)의 중요성이 낮아졌다는 거였어요. 회사에서 칭찬받는 사람들은 마케팅(marketing), 영업(sales), 재무(finance) 같은 사람들이죠. 그리고 회사가 혁신을 멈추면 이 사람들이 성장(growth)의 엔진이라고 여겨지는데, 사실은 성장을 만들어낸다기보다 비용 절감(cost-cutting)으로 조직을 굴리는 쪽이에요.
text_zh: 他的观点是，公司规模越大，产品就越不重要了。公司里受到重视的都是做市场的、跑销售的、搞财务的人。如果一个公司不再创新了，那增长就只能靠这些了——销售、市场营销，财务虽然不能带来增长，但至少能控制成本。
text_es: Y su argumento era que mientras más grande se vuelve una empresa, históricamente el producto va perdiendo importancia. La gente que celebraban en la compañía eran los de marketing, los de ventas, los de finanzas. Si una empresa deja de innovar, estos son los motores de crecimiento. Ventas, marketing, o bueno, con finanzas no es crecimiento, sino recortar costos.
context: Lenny asks about insights from Steve Jobs's lost interview documentary. Marty explains Jobs's theory about why companies lose their product innovation edge as they grow. According to Jobs, as companies get larger and stop innovating, the focus shifts from product development to other functions like sales, marketing, and finance, which become the primary drivers of business results. These non-product functions then gain more influence and recognition within the company.
vocabulary_highlights: engines for growth
topics: Product Management, Leadership & Management, Strategy & Planning

speaker: Marty Cagan
text: And he called it the disease of the stakeholders, of the managers, where they think that an idea is 90% of the work. And that's how he called it out. And he's like, 'They don't understand. The idea is minor. The idea is just to start.' I think he said, 'The whole craftsmanship of going from an idea to a product.' This is what we call product discovery.
text_ko: 그는 그걸 이해관계자들이나 관리자들이 가진 병이라고 불렀어요. 그 사람들이 아이디어가 일의 90%라고 생각한다고 꼬집었죠. '그들은 모르는 거야. 아이디어는 사소해. 아이디어는 그냥 시작일 뿐이야.'라고 말했고, '아이디어에서 제품으로 가는 전체적인 장인정신'이라고 했던 것 같아요. 이게 우리가 제품 발견(product discovery)이라고 부르는 거예요.
text_zh: 他把这个叫做利益相关者和管理层的通病，就是他们觉得有了想法就等于完成了90%的工作。他就是这么说的。他说："他们根本不懂，想法其实很次要，想法只是个开始而已。"我记得他说过："从想法到产品这整个打磨过程才是关键。"这就是我们说的产品探索(product discovery)。
text_es: Y él le puso "la enfermedad de los stakeholders, de los managers", donde piensan que una idea es el 90% del trabajo. Así lo describió. Y decía: "No entienden. La idea es lo de menos. La idea es solo para empezar." Creo que dijo algo como "Todo el arte de llevar una idea hasta convertirla en producto." A eso le llamamos product discovery.
context: Lenny asks about executives who believe they know exactly what to build without going through discovery processes. Marty references Steve Jobs's insights about management diseases, specifically the misconception that having an idea represents most of the work in product development. Jobs emphasized that ideas are just starting points, and the real work lies in the craftsmanship of transforming ideas into successful products through what is now called product discovery.
vocabulary_highlights: disease of the stakeholders, craftsmanship

speaker: Matt Abrahams
text: You actually have to prepare to be spontaneous. And that's counterintuitive, but when you think about it in athletics or jazz music, it's like of course you would prepare and practice.
text_ko: 사실 즉흥적(spontaneous)이 되려면 미리 준비해야 해요. 직관에 어긋나는(counterintuitive) 말이긴 하지만, 운동이나 재즈 음악을 생각해 보면 당연히 준비하고 연습하잖아요.
text_zh: 其实你得为即兴发挥做准备，这听起来挺矛盾的，但你想想体育或者爵士乐，当然要提前准备和练习啊。
text_es: En realidad tienes que prepararte para ser espontáneo. Y sí, suena contradictorio, pero si lo piensas en el deporte o en el jazz, pues claro que te vas a preparar y practicar.
context: Lenny points out that most public speaking we do is on the spot rather than prepared talks. Matt responds by explaining one of the fundamental principles for getting better at spontaneous speaking. He argues that while it seems contradictory, you must actually prepare in order to be effective when speaking spontaneously, just like athletes and jazz musicians practice extensively to perform well in unpredictable situations.
vocabulary_highlights: counterintuitive

speaker: Matt Abrahams
text: Strive for connection over perfection by daring to be dull. Just answer the question. Just give the feedback. Just be engaged in the small talk. By doing that, you dial down the volume of self-evaluation, freeing up resources that can be used to really help you succeed.
text_ko: 완벽함보다 연결을 목표로 하세요. 지루해지는 걸 감수할 용기를 내보세요. 그냥 질문에 답하세요. 그냥 피드백을 주세요. 그냥 가벼운 잡담에 참여하세요. 그러면 자기평가의 소음을 낮추고, 그 여유를 진짜 성공에 도움이 되는 일에 쓸 수 있어요.
text_zh: 与其追求完美，不如专注建立联系，敢于做个"普通人"。问什么答什么，该给反馈就给反馈，闲聊的时候就好好参与进去。这样做能让你不那么纠结自己的表现，把精力真正用在能让你成功的事情上。
text_es: Busca conectar en lugar de ser perfecto, y atrévete a ser aburrido. Simplemente responde la pregunta. Simplemente da el feedback. Simplemente participa en la plática casual. Al hacer eso, reduces la autocrítica mental, liberando energía que puedes usar para realmente tener éxito.
context: Lenny asks about techniques for calming anxiety when speaking. Matt explains his "dare to be dull" concept, which comes from improvisation. He argues that when we try to be perfect in communication, we waste mental bandwidth on self-evaluation rather than focusing on connecting with our audience and delivering our message effectively.
vocabulary_highlights: strive for connection over perfection, daring to be dull, dial down the volume

speaker: Matt Abrahams
text: Visualization is a really useful technique and you see yourself not just in the moment of speaking, but getting up to the stage, seeing it being well received, thinking about how you step off the stage. We see athletes do this kind of thing all the time, and there's good research to say that this desensitizes people.
text_ko: 시각화(visualization)는 정말 유용한 기법이에요. 말하는 순간만 떠올리는 게 아니라 무대에 오르는 모습, 청중이 잘 받아주는 모습, 무대에서 내려오는 장면까지 미리 상상해 보는 거예요. 운동선수들이 늘 이렇게 하는 걸 보잖아요. 연구도 있어서 이런 연습이 두려움이나 긴장에 덜 민감해지게 만든다고 해요.
text_zh: 想象练习真的特别管用，你要想象的不只是站在台上讲话的那一刻，还要想象自己走上台、看到观众反应很好、然后怎么走下台，整个过程都要过一遍。你看那些运动员经常这么做，研究也证明了这样能让人没那么紧张。
text_es: La visualización es una técnica súper útil donde te imaginas no solo el momento de hablar, sino también cómo subes al escenario, cómo tu presentación es bien recibida, cómo bajas del escenario después. Vemos que los deportistas hacen esto todo el tiempo, y hay buena investigación que demuestra que esto ayuda a desensibilizar a la gente.
context: Lenny asks Matt to explain visualization as a technique for managing speaking anxiety, moving away from the old "picture the audience naked" advice. Matt describes proper visualization as a mental rehearsal where you imagine the entire speaking experience from start to finish, including positive audience reception. This technique, commonly used by athletes, helps desensitize speakers to anxiety-provoking situations.
vocabulary_highlights: desensitizes

speaker: Matt Abrahams
text: When we communicate, especially spontaneously, we want to do it really well. We want to answer the question with the best answer, we want to give the right feedback, we want to be the most interesting in small talk and that puts a lot of pressure on ourselves. And you can think of it this way, it's really taxing our cognitive bandwidth.
text_ko: 우리가 소통할 때, 특히 즉흥적으로 대화할 때는 정말 잘하려고 해요. 질문에는 가장 좋은 답을 하려고 하고, 적절한 피드백을 주려고 하며, 스몰 토크(small talk)에서는 가장 흥미로운 사람이 되려고 하죠. 그래서 스스로에게 많은 압박을 주게 되고, 말하자면 우리의 인지적 대역폭(cognitive bandwidth)을 정말 많이 소모하고 있어요.
text_zh: 我们沟通的时候，特别是临场发挥的时候，总想表现得特别好。想给出最完美的答案，想提最到位的反馈，闲聊的时候也想成为最有意思的那个人，这样一来就给自己施加了很大压力。你可以这样想，这其实是在大量消耗我们的认知带宽(cognitive bandwidth)。
text_es: Cuando nos comunicamos, sobre todo de forma espontánea, queremos hacerlo súper bien. Queremos dar la mejor respuesta posible, queremos dar el feedback correcto, queremos ser los más interesantes en la plática casual y eso nos pone mucha presión encima. Y puedes verlo así: realmente está agotando nuestra capacidad cognitiva (cognitive bandwidth).
context: Matt is explaining his "dare to be dull" philosophy in more detail. He describes how our desire to excel in communication creates mental pressure that actually hinders our performance. By comparing the brain to a computer's CPU, he illustrates how perfectionism consumes mental resources that could be better used for actual communication and connection.
vocabulary_highlights: taxing our cognitive bandwidth

speaker: Matt Abrahams
text: So how we label the arousal matters and what Alison's research and others have followed up with suggests is that when we feel those symptoms of anxiety, rather than seeing it as negative, say, 'This is exciting. I get to share my point of view. I get to demonstrate my value.' And in so doing by seeing it as more positive, it causes us by definition to relax.
text_ko: 그래서 우리가 각성(arousal)을 어떻게 해석하느냐가 중요해요. 앨리슨의 연구와 그 후속 연구들이 보여주는 건, 불안한 증상이 느껴질 때 그걸 부정적으로 보지 말고 "이거 신나네. 내 관점을 공유할 기회다. 내 가치를 보여줄 수 있겠네."라고 생각하라는 거예요. 그렇게 더 긍정적으로 보면 자연히 긴장이 풀려요.
text_zh: 所以我们怎么理解这种紧张感很关键。艾莉森的研究还有后续的一些研究都表明，当我们感到焦虑的时候，与其把它看成负面情绪，不如告诉自己"这挺让人兴奋的，我可以分享我的观点，我可以展示我的价值"。这样一来，把它往积极的方向想，自然就放松了。
text_es: Entonces, cómo etiquetamos esa activación importa mucho, y lo que sugiere la investigación de Alison y otros estudios que han seguido es que cuando sentimos esos síntomas de ansiedad, en lugar de verlo como algo negativo, digamos: "Esto es emocionante. Tengo la oportunidad de compartir mi punto de vista. Puedo demostrar mi valor." Y al hacerlo, al verlo de manera más positiva, automáticamente nos hace relajarnos.
context: Lenny asks about the technique of reframing nervousness as excitement. Matt explains research by Alison Wood Brooks showing that anxiety and excitement produce the same physiological response in our bodies - increased heart rate, shallow breathing, shakiness. The key difference is how we interpret these sensations. By consciously labeling the arousal as excitement rather than anxiety, we can actually improve our communication performance.
vocabulary_highlights: label the arousal, by definition

speaker: Matt Abrahams
text: We are very susceptible to catastrophizing when we're very nervous about things, especially when we're exposed in front of people. Not in the Brady Bunch exposure we talked about earlier, but when we're out there speaking or communicating and simply reminding ourselves that often they go very well is helpful.
text_ko: 사람들 앞에서 드러나야 하는 상황처럼 뭔가에 대해 몹시 긴장하면 우리는 파국화(catastrophizing)에 쉽게 빠져요. 앞서 얘기한 브래디 번치(Brady Bunch)식 노출을 말하는 건 아니고, 실제로 나가서 말하거나 소통할 때를 말하는 거예요. 그런 상황들이 의외로 잘 풀리는 경우가 많다는 걸 스스로 떠올리는 것만으로도 도움이 돼요.
text_zh: 我们特别容易往最坏处想，尤其是紧张的时候，特别是要在大家面前露面的时候。这里说的不是我们之前提到的那种家庭式的暴露，而是当我们要在台上讲话或者跟人沟通的时候。这时候提醒自己其实大部分情况下都会进行得很顺利，这样想会很有帮助。
text_es: Tendemos mucho a ponernos en lo peor cuando estamos muy nerviosos por algo, sobre todo cuando estamos expuestos delante de la gente. No me refiero a esa exposición tipo familia perfecta de la que hablamos antes, sino cuando estamos ahí hablando o comunicándonos, y simplemente recordarnos que normalmente las cosas salen bien nos ayuda bastante.
context: Matt is discussing mantras as anxiety management tools, sharing examples like "I have value to add" and "Last time this went well." He explains how negative self-talk undermines our confidence, and how positive mantras can counter our tendency to imagine worst-case scenarios. The reference to "Brady Bunch exposure" playfully recalls their earlier discussion about the flawed advice of imagining audiences naked.
vocabulary_highlights: susceptible to catastrophizing

speaker: Matt Abrahams
text: Those of us who study this believe it is innate to being human to feel nervous communicating in front of others. So sometimes just reminding yourself that you're not alone and that others have it can actually help reduce the pressure that we feel.
text_ko: 이걸 연구하는 사람들은 사람은 남 앞에서 말할 때 긴장하는 게 인간의 본성에 가깝다고 봐요. 그래서 가끔 '나만 그런 게 아니야, 다른 사람들도 그래'라고 스스로 상기시키는 것만으로도 우리가 느끼는 부담을 줄이는 데 도움이 돼요.
text_zh: 我们研究这个领域的人都认为，在别人面前说话感到紧张，这是人的天性。所以有时候提醒自己"不是只有我一个人这样，大家都会紧张"，其实就能帮你减轻不少压力。
text_es: Los que estudiamos esto creemos que es algo natural del ser humano sentirse nervioso al comunicarse delante de otros. Así que a veces simplemente recordarte que no estás solo y que otros también lo sienten puede ayudarte a reducir esa presión que sentimos.
context: Matt tells a story about meeting someone at an airport who found his book on speaking anxiety helpful without even reading it - just knowing such a book existed made the person feel better. This leads to Matt's broader point about normalizing communication anxiety. He explains that researchers believe nervousness about public speaking is a natural human trait, not a personal failing.
vocabulary_highlights: innate to being human

speaker: Matt Dixon
text: We collected two and a half million sales calls and studied them with a machine learning platform at scale. What we found is that anywhere between 40 and 60% of the average salesperson's qualified pipelines will be ultimately marked as closed loss, no decision. If you think about as a salesperson, that for 46% of your deals, you're going to spend a lot of time, energy, resources pursuing these opportunities where you eventually just get ghosted.
text_ko: 우리는 250만 건이 넘는 영업 통화를 모아 대규모 머신러닝 플랫폼(machine learning platform)으로 분석했어요. 그 결과 평균 영업사원의 적격 파이프라인(qualified pipelines) 중 약 40~60%가 결국 'closed loss, no decision'(closed loss, no decision)로 처리된다는 걸 발견했어요. 영업사원 관점에서 보면 거래의 약 46%는 많은 시간과 에너지, 자원을 들여 기회를 쫓다가 결국 상대가 연락을 끊어 아무 결정도 못 내리는 경우라는 뜻이에요.
text_zh: 我们收集了两百五十万通销售电话，用机器学习平台(machine learning platform)大规模地分析了这些数据。我们发现，普通销售人员有资质的销售管道(qualified pipeline)中，大概有40%到60%最终都会被标记为败单，客户没做决定就没下文了。你想想看，作为销售，你46%的单子都是这样——你投入大把时间、精力和资源去跟进这些机会，到头来客户直接把你晾在那儿，音信全无。
text_es: Recopilamos dos millones y medio de llamadas de ventas y las analizamos usando una plataforma de machine learning a gran escala. Lo que descubrimos es que entre el 40 y 60% de las oportunidades calificadas del vendedor promedio terminan marcándose como pérdida cerrada, sin decisión. Si lo piensas como vendedor, en el 46% de tus deals vas a invertir muchísimo tiempo, energía y recursos persiguiendo estas oportunidades donde al final simplemente te van a hacer ghosting.
context: Lenny asks Matt to explain the research methodology behind his books on sales. Matt describes their massive data collection effort during the pandemic when sales moved to virtual platforms, allowing them to analyze millions of sales conversations. He reveals a surprising finding about how many qualified sales opportunities - not just random leads, but real prospects that salespeople have invested time in - end up being lost not to competitors, but to customer indecision where prospects simply disappear without making any decision.
vocabulary_highlights: qualified pipelines, closed loss, no decision, get ghosted

speaker: Matt Dixon
text: Dialing up the FOMO backfires 87% of the time. They're not afraid of missing out, they're afraid of messing up. What salespeople have been armed to do is go out and dial up the FOMO and make the customer sweat a little bit. The FOMU actually matters more than the FOMO. The FOMU is the fear of messing up.
text_ko: 놓칠까 봐 두려움(FOMO)을 부추기면 87%의 경우에 역효과가 나요. 사람들은 단순히 놓치는 게 무서운 게 아니라, 망칠까 봐 더 무서워해요. 영업사원들은 FOMO를 부풀려서 고객을 좀 초조하게 만들라고 훈련받아 왔어요. 그런데 사실 놓칠까 봐 두려움(FOMO)보다 망칠까 봐 두려움(FOMU)이 더 중요해요. FOMU는 일을 망치거나 실수할까 봐 느끼는 두려움이에요.
text_zh: 一味地制造饥饿营销，十次有八九次都会适得其反。客户真正担心的不是错过机会，而是怕做错决定。销售们现在的套路就是拼命制造紧迫感，让客户心里着急。其实客户更在乎的是别搞砸了，而不是怕错过什么。真正起作用的是"怕搞砸心理"(FOMU)，而不是"错失恐惧"(FOMO)。
text_es: Intensificar el FOMO falla el 87% de las veces. No tienen miedo de perderse algo, tienen miedo de cagarla. A los vendedores los han entrenado para salir y crear más FOMO, para hacer que el cliente sude un poco. Pero en realidad el FOMU importa más que el FOMO. El FOMU es el miedo de cagarla (fear of messing up).
context: Matt explains a key insight from analyzing millions of sales calls about why traditional sales tactics fail. When customers hesitate before making a purchase decision, most salespeople try to create urgency by emphasizing what the customer will miss out on (FOMO - fear of missing out). However, Matt's research shows this approach actually makes things worse 87% of the time because customers aren't worried about missing opportunities - they're terrified of being personally blamed if the purchase decision goes wrong.
vocabulary_highlights: dialing up the FOMO, make the customer sweat, FOMU

speaker: Matt Dixon
text: The first thing is we've got to judge their level of indecision. The second thing is we've got to offer a recommendation. The third thing is we've got to get them to start trusting us and we call it limit the exploration, and the T is we've got to de-risk the deal. We've got to take some risk off the table.
text_ko: 첫 번째로는 그들의 결정 장애 수준을 파악해야 해요. 두 번째로는 추천을 해줘야 하고요. 세 번째로는 그들이 우리를 신뢰하게 만들어야 해요. 이걸 '탐색 제한(limit the exploration)'이라고 부르고요. 마지막으로는 거래의 리스크를 줄여야 해요. 위험 요소를 덜어내는 게 중요해요.
text_zh: 首先呢，我们得看看他们到底有多纠结。然后我们得给个建议，让他们知道该怎么办。第三点就是要让他们开始信任我们，我们叫这个"限制探索"(limit the exploration)。最后这个T就是要给这个deal降降风险，把一些风险因素先排除掉。
text_es: Lo primero que tenemos que hacer es evaluar qué tan indecisos están. Lo segundo es darles una recomendación clara. Lo tercero es lograr que empiecen a confiar en nosotros, y a esto le decimos limitar la exploración (limit the exploration), y la T es que tenemos que quitar el riesgo del negocio. Tenemos que eliminar parte del riesgo de la ecuación.
context: Lenny asks Matt about his JOLT method for improving sales processes based on his research insights. Matt explains that JOLT is an acronym for a four-step approach to help customers overcome their fear of making bad decisions. The method addresses the core problem that customers want to buy but can't because they're paralyzed by fear of failure, so salespeople need to systematically reduce that fear and guide them toward a decision they feel confident about.
vocabulary_highlights: judge their level of indecision, limit the exploration, de-risk the deal, take some risk off the table

speaker: Matt Dixon
text: Most salespeople are trying to figure out what's keeping the customer up at night. The challenger approach is about showing the customer what should be keeping them up at night. What's a risk that they don't know about but you do. You are a window into the outside world for them, and that's what challengers really understand.
text_ko: 대부분의 영업 담당자들(salespeople)은 고객이 밤에 잠 못 이루게 하는 게 뭔지 알아내려고 해요. 챌린저 접근법(challenger approach)은 고객이 실제로 신경 써야 할 문제를 알려주는 거예요. 고객은 모르는데 당신은 알고 있는 리스크(risk)가 무엇인지 찾아내는 거죠. 당신은 그들에게 외부 세상을 보여주는 창이고, 바로 그걸 챌린저들(challengers)은 정말 잘 이해해요.
text_zh: 大多数销售都在琢磨客户现在最头疼什么问题。但挑战者销售法(challenger approach)不一样，是要让客户意识到他们应该担心什么。就是那些他们还没发现、但你知道的风险点。你其实就是他们了解外面世界的一扇窗，这就是挑战者真正懂的道理。
text_es: La mayoría de los vendedores están tratando de descubrir qué es lo que no deja dormir al cliente. El enfoque retador (challenger approach) se trata de mostrarle al cliente qué debería quitarle el sueño. ¿Cuál es ese riesgo que ellos no conocen pero tú sí? Tú eres su ventana al mundo exterior, y eso es lo que los retadores realmente entienden.
context: Matt contrasts traditional sales approaches with his Challenger Sale methodology. Traditional salespeople focus on identifying existing customer problems and pain points. The Challenger approach flips this - instead of just responding to what customers already know they need, top salespeople proactively educate customers about risks and opportunities they haven't considered yet. This works because salespeople talk to many more customers and have broader market insight than any individual buyer.
vocabulary_highlights: keeping the customer up at night, window into the outside world

speaker: Matt Dixon
text: Indecision stems from their fear of failure. The omission bias is the fact that people don't want to be blamed for making decisions that lead to a loss. There are losses that happen when we do nothing, and then there are losses that happened because we did something. In the human mind, people are okay with missing out. They are not okay with messing up and being blamed.
text_ko: 우유부단함은 실패에 대한 두려움에서 나와요. 생략 편향(omission bias)은 사람들이 손실로 이어지는 결정을 내렸다고 비난받는 걸 원하지 않는다는 뜻이에요. 아무것도 안 해서 생기는 손실도 있고, 뭔가 해서 생기는 손실도 있어요. 사람들은 놓치는 건 괜찮다고 생각하지만, 실수해서 비난받는 건 참기 어려워해요.
text_zh: 犹豫不决其实就是怕搞砸。有个偏见叫"不作为偏差"(omission bias)，就是说人们不想因为自己的决定导致损失而被人指责。损失有两种，一种是我们什么都不做造成的，另一种是我们采取行动造的。在人的心理上，大家都能接受错过机会，但是接受不了自己搞砸了还要被人埋怨。
text_es: La indecisión viene del miedo al fracaso. El sesgo de omisión (omission bias) es que la gente no quiere que la culpen por tomar decisiones que llevan a pérdidas. Hay pérdidas que pasan cuando no hacemos nada, y hay pérdidas que pasan porque sí hicimos algo. En la mente humana, la gente acepta perderse oportunidades. Lo que no aceptan es meter la pata y que los señalen.
context: Matt explains the psychological research behind customer indecision, drawing from cognitive psychology studies. He describes 'omission bias' - a powerful human tendency where people prefer losses that happen from inaction over losses that result from their active decisions. This bias is even stronger than status quo bias (preferring to keep things the same). Understanding this helps explain why customers who want to buy a product still hesitate - they're not worried about missing benefits, they're terrified of being personally blamed if their purchase decision leads to problems.
vocabulary_highlights: omission bias, messing up and being blamed

speaker: Matt Dixon
text: We found a technique called pings and echoes that high performers use. The way this works is that a salesperson will try to articulate but in a non, not to out the customer, but to get confirmation or refutation that what they've articulated is actually a concern for their buyer. At this point, most customers like you, are thinking about this or they're worried about that.
text_ko: 우리는 성과가 높은 사람들이 쓰는 '핑스 앤 에코스(pings and echoes)'라는 기법을 발견했어요. 이 방법은 영업 담당자가 고객을 곤란하게 하려는 게 아니라, 자신이 말로 정리한 게 실제로 구매자의 고민인지 확인(또는 부정)받으려는 식으로 표현해 보는 거예요. 이 시점에서 대부분의 고객들, 즉 당신 같은 분들은 이걸 생각하고 있거나 저걸 걱정하고 계신 경우가 많아요.
text_zh: 我们发现高绩效销售员会用一个叫"试探回应(pings and echoes)"的技巧。具体是这样的：销售员会把客户可能的顾虑说出来，但不是为了让客户难堪，而是想确认一下自己说的是不是真的击中了客户的痛点。比如会说"像您这样的客户，现在多半都在考虑这个问题"或者"都在担心那个事情"。
text_es: Descubrimos una técnica que usan los vendedores top que se llama "pings and echoes" (señales y respuestas). Funciona así: el vendedor trata de expresar algo, pero no para poner en evidencia al cliente, sino para conseguir que le confirme o le diga que no - que lo que está planteando realmente le preocupa al comprador. En este punto, la mayoría de clientes como usted están pensando en esto o les preocupa aquello.
context: Matt describes a specific technique discovered in their research for the first step of the JOLT method - judging a customer's level of indecision. The 'pings and echoes' technique works like sonar - salespeople send out a 'ping' by suggesting what many customers worry about at this stage, then listen for the customer's response (the 'echo') to understand their specific concerns. This approach works because customers often won't directly admit they're indecisive or afraid, so salespeople need a subtle way to surface these concerns without embarrassing the customer.
vocabulary_highlights: pings and echoes, not to out the customer, confirmation or refutation

speaker: Matt Dixon
text: What great salespeople do though is they know that while they'll stand by those claims, those case studies, those proof points, they try to kind of under-promise and over-deliver. What I'd rather we do is build your business case around a 5X improvement because we see that at least that, in 100% of our implementations. Then, let's set up to over-deliver against that.
text_ko: 훌륭한 세일즈맨들은 자신이 한 주장이나 사례 연구, 증거를 지키는 동시에, 약속은 조금 낮게 하고 실제로는 더 많은 가치를 제공하려고 해요. 그래서 저는 우리가 비즈니스 케이스를 5배 향상에 맞춰서 만들면 좋겠어요. 왜냐하면 저희의 모든 프로젝트에서 최소한 그 정도는 보장하거든요. 그럼 그 목표를 초과 달성할 수 있도록 준비해보죠.
text_zh: 不过优秀的销售都懂一个道理，虽然他们会坚持自己说的那些承诺、案例研究和证明材料，但他们会尽量少承诺、多兑现。我更愿意这样做：咱们围绕5倍的提升来构建你的商业论证，因为在我们100%的实施案例中，至少都能达到这个水平。然后，我们再在这个基础上超额交付。
text_es: Lo que hacen los vendedores realmente buenos es que saben que aunque van a respaldar esas afirmaciones, esos casos de estudio, esos puntos de prueba, tratan de prometer menos y entregar más. Lo que prefiero que hagamos es construir tu caso de negocio alrededor de una mejora de 5X porque vemos al menos eso en el 100% de nuestras implementaciones. Entonces, preparémonos para superar esas expectativas.
context: Matt explains a key technique for the final step of JOLT - taking risk off the table for nervous customers. When customers get excited about impressive case studies showing dramatic results, average salespeople let them build high expectations. However, top performers deliberately reset expectations to more conservative but guaranteed outcomes. This reduces the customer's fear that they won't achieve the promised results and get blamed for the purchase. By setting lower expectations, salespeople make it more likely the customer will feel confident about the decision and be pleasantly surprised by the actual results.
vocabulary_highlights: stand by those claims, under-promise and over-deliver, set up to over-deliver

speaker: Matt LeMay
speaker_expertise: Product Management, Team Building, Product Strategy
text: It's important because at the end of the day, it is those business critical outcomes against which you and your team will be evaluated. That's the reality of working for a business, right? If you are contributing to the business in a way that the business at large can understand, that the CEO can understand, that the CFO can understand, if your team is a good investment for the business, then the business will continue making that investment.
text_ko: 중요한 이유는 결국 당신과 당신의 팀이 평가받는 기준이 바로 그런 비즈니스 핵심 성과(business critical outcomes)이기 때문이에요. 회사에서 일하는 현실이 그런 거잖아요. 조직 전체와 최고경영자(CEO), 최고재무책임자(CFO)까지 이해할 수 있는 방식으로 비즈니스에 기여하면, 당신의 팀이 회사에 투자할 만한 가치가 있다는 판단을 받을 거예요. 그러면 회사는 그 투자를 계속하게 될 거예요.
text_zh: 这个很重要，因为说到底，你和你的团队会根据这些关键业务成果来被评估。在公司工作就是这个现实，对吧？如果你对业务的贡献是整个公司都能理解的，CEO能理解的，CFO也能理解的，如果你的团队对公司来说是个好投资，那公司就会继续在你们身上投钱。
text_es: Es importante porque al final del día, van a evaluar a tu equipo y a ti en base a esos resultados críticos para el negocio. Esa es la realidad de trabajar en una empresa, ¿no? Si estás contribuyendo al negocio de una manera que toda la empresa pueda entender, que el CEO pueda entender, que el CFO pueda entender, si tu equipo es una buena inversión para el negocio, entonces la empresa va a seguir haciendo esa inversión.
context: Lenny asks Matt why aligning work to business critical outcomes is so important. Matt explains that product managers and teams are increasingly being laid off, and CEOs are explicitly stating they have 'too many teams doing work around the work' rather than focusing on real impact. Matt emphasizes that teams will ultimately be evaluated based on their contribution to business critical outcomes, not on following best practices or shipping features.
vocabulary_highlights: business critical outcomes, good investment, continue making that investment
topics: Product Management, Strategy & Planning, Leadership & Management

speaker: Matt LeMay
speaker_expertise: Product Management, Team Building, Product Strategy
text: The message that Daniel Ek from Spotify sent out with their layoffs in 2024 said, 'We still have too many teams doing work around the work and supporting work, rather than focusing on opportunities with real impact.' And that really struck a nerve because I've been on those supporting teams before. I've done the work around the work.
text_ko: 다니엘 에크(Daniel Ek)가 2024년 해고와 관련해 보낸 메시지에서 '우리는 여전히 실제로 영향력 있는 기회에 집중하기보다는 일을 지원하는 팀이 너무 많다'고 했어요. 이 말이 정말 와닿았어요. 저도 예전에 그런 지원 팀에서 일해본 적이 있거든요. 일을 둘러싼 일을 한 경험이 있어요.
text_zh: Spotify的Daniel Ek在2024年裁员时发的那个消息说，"我们还是有太多团队在做一些围绕工作的工作，做一些支持性的工作，而不是专注于那些真正有影响力的机会。" 这话真的戳中了我的痛点，因为我以前就在那种支持团队里待过，我也做过那种为了工作而工作的事情。
text_es: El mensaje que mandó Daniel Ek de Spotify cuando hicieron los recortes en 2024 decía: "Todavía tenemos demasiados equipos haciendo trabajo alrededor del trabajo y apoyando el trabajo, en lugar de enfocarse en oportunidades con impacto real." Y eso realmente me tocó la fibra porque yo he estado en esos equipos de apoyo antes. He hecho ese trabajo alrededor del trabajo.
context: Lenny asks what this focus on business impact is a reaction to, wondering why many product teams aren't already driving business impact. Matt explains that more product managers and teams are being laid off, citing a specific example from Spotify's CEO Daniel Ek who explicitly stated the problem: too many teams doing 'work around the work' instead of focusing on real impact.
vocabulary_highlights: struck a nerve, work around the work, supporting work

speaker: Matt LeMay
speaker_expertise: Product Management, Team Building, Product Strategy
text: So the first question I ask most of the teams I work with is if you were the CEO of this company, would you fully fund your own team? And frankly, most of the people I ask that question to don't know the answer right away. They're not sure. They say, 'I think so,' or, 'Yeah, yeah. Yeah, because...' And then you can see the gears turning.
text_ko: 제가 함께 일하는 팀들한테 가장 먼저 묻는 질문이 있어요. "만약 당신이 이 회사의 CEO라면, 자신의 팀에 전적으로 자금을 대겠어요?" 솔직히 말하면 그 질문을 받는 사람들 대부분은 바로 답을 못해요. 확신이 없죠. "그럴 것 같아요" 또는 "네, 네. 왜냐하면…" 하고 말하면서 머릿속에서 생각이 돌아가는 게 보여요.
text_zh: 所以我和团队合作时，第一个问题通常是：如果你是这家公司的CEO，你会全力支持自己的团队吗？说实话，大部分人听到这个问题都答不上来，不太确定。他们会说"应该会吧"，或者"嗯嗯，会的，因为..."然后你就能看出他们在那儿琢磨。
text_es: Entonces la primera pregunta que les hago a la mayoría de los equipos con los que trabajo es: si ustedes fueran el CEO de esta empresa, ¿financiarían completamente a su propio equipo? Y la verdad, la mayoría de las personas a las que les hago esa pregunta no saben la respuesta de inmediato. No están seguros. Dicen "Creo que sí" o "Sí, sí. Sí, porque..." Y ahí puedes ver cómo se les mueven los engranajes.
context: Lenny asks for ways product managers can stress test whether they're actually driving impact or just think they are. Matt shares his go-to question for teams he works with: asking them to think like a CEO and consider whether they would fully fund their own team. He notes that most people can't answer this confidently, which indicates they may not understand their team's true value to the business.
vocabulary_highlights: fully fund, gears turning
topics: Product Management, Strategy & Planning, Decision Making

speaker: Matt LeMay
speaker_expertise: Product Management, Team Building, Product Strategy
text: The Low Impact Death Spiral is the dynamic in which every medium to large company I've ever worked with finds itself in one way or another. It starts with teams taking on low impact work. Adding little features here and there, making little cosmetic improvements because it's easier, it invites less scrutiny and you're less likely to mess up something important.
text_ko: 영향이 적은 데스 스파이럴(Low Impact Death Spiral)은 제가 일해본 거의 모든 중대형 회사들이 어떤 식으로든 빠져 있는 역학이에요. 보통 팀들이 영향이 적은 업무(low-impact work)를 맡는 것부터 시작돼요. 여기저기 작은 기능을 붙이거나, 보기 좋게 하는 정도의 사소한 개선만 하는 식인데, 그게 더 쉽고 검토도 덜 들어오니까 중요한 걸 망칠 위험이 적거든요.
text_zh: 低影响死亡螺旋(Low Impact Death Spiral)这个现象，我合作过的中大型公司基本都会碰到。一开始呢，团队就爱接一些没什么影响力的活儿。这里加个小功能，那里改改界面什么的，做些表面功夫，因为这样省事儿嘛，不容易被人挑毛病，也不太可能把重要的东西搞砸。
text_es: La Espiral de la Muerte de Bajo Impacto es esa dinámica en la que se meten todas las empresas medianas y grandes con las que he trabajado, de una forma u otra. Empieza cuando los equipos se enfocan en trabajo de poco impacto. Van agregando funcionalidades menores por aquí y por allá, haciendo mejoritas cosméticas porque es más fácil, genera menos ruido con los jefes y hay menos chance de que la riegues con algo importante.
context: Lenny asks Matt to explain the 'Low Impact PM Death Spiral' concept from his book. Matt describes this as a common dynamic where product teams gravitate toward low-risk, low-impact work like small features and cosmetic improvements because it's safer and invites less scrutiny. This creates a cycle where low-impact work makes it harder to do high-impact work, leading teams deeper into irrelevant projects until layoffs occur.
vocabulary_highlights: death spiral, invites less scrutiny, cosmetic improvements

speaker: Matt LeMay
speaker_expertise: Product Management, Team Building, Product Strategy
text: You can follow all the best practices and have the highest velocity and do everything quote-unquote 'right', but if your company goes out of business, they're not going to say, 'Yeah, we're going out of business, but we're going to keep writing your paycheck for two years because all of your OKRs were a 0.6 or a 0.7.'
text_ko: 모든 최선의 방법을 따르고, 속도도 최고로 유지하고, 모든 걸 '제대로' 해도, 만약 회사가 망하게 된다면, '그래, 우리는 망하지만, 너의 OKR이 0.6이나 0.7이었으니까 2년 동안 너의 월급은 계속 줄게'라고 하진 않을 거예요.
text_zh: 你可以遵循所有最佳实践，保持最高的执行速度，把所谓的"正确"事情都做到位，但如果公司倒闭了，他们不会说："是的，我们要关门了，不过因为你所有的OKRs都达到了0.6或0.7的完成度，所以我们还会继续给你发两年工资。"
text_es: Puedes seguir todas las mejores prácticas y tener la velocidad más alta y hacer todo "como debe ser", pero si tu empresa quiebra, no te van a decir: "Sí, nos vamos a la quiebra, pero te vamos a seguir pagando el sueldo dos años más porque todos tus OKRs estuvieron en 0.6 o 0.7."
context: Matt discusses the emotional challenge of being accountable for things outside our control, like business impact that depends on market conditions and customer behavior. He explains that while we naturally want to avoid accountability for uncontrollable factors, the reality is that business success affects us regardless. He uses this example to illustrate that following best practices doesn't protect you if the business fails.
vocabulary_highlights: quote-unquote, writing your paycheck, OKRs
topics: Product Management, Strategy & Planning, Work-Life Balance

speaker: Matt LeMay
speaker_expertise: Product Management, Team Building, Product Strategy
text: So the first step, and I think the most important and where a lot of my work plays out is in setting team goals, close to company goals. No more than one step away from company goals. Don't let it get cascaded into oblivion.
text_ko: 그래서 첫 번째 단계이자 제가 가장 중요하다고 생각하는 건 팀 목표를 회사 목표에 최대한 가깝게, 즉 회사 목표에서 한 단계 이내로 설정하는 거예요. 목표가 하향식으로 전파(cascade)되면서 흐지부지해지지 않도록 하세요.
text_zh: 所以第一步，也是我觉得最关键的一步，也是我大部分工作重点，就是设定团队目标，要跟公司目标紧密挂钩。最多只能偏离公司目标一步，千万别让目标在层层传递中变得面目全非。
text_es: Entonces el primer paso, y creo que es el más importante y donde se concentra gran parte de mi trabajo, es definir objetivos de equipo que estén muy alineados con los objetivos de la empresa. Como máximo un escalón por debajo de los objetivos corporativos. No dejes que se diluyan pasando de nivel en nivel hasta que no signifiquen nada.
context: Lenny asks about Matt's three steps to become more of an impact-first product team. Matt explains the first and most critical step: setting team goals that are no more than one step away from company goals. He references Christina Wodtke's concept from 'Radical Focus' about avoiding multi-level goal cascading that leads to team goals that can't be traced back to company objectives.
vocabulary_highlights: cascaded into oblivion
topics: Product Management, Strategy & Planning, Leadership & Management

speaker: Matt MacInnis
text: If you want to accomplish something truly extraordinary, if you want to be in the 99th percentile in terms of outcomes, it's going to be really difficult. It's going to be really uncomfortable. And you got to sort of remind people of that, that if they ever find themselves in the comfort zone at work, they are definitely making a mistake.
text_ko: 정말 특별한 성과를 내고 싶고, 결과 면에서 상위 1퍼센타일(99th percentile)에 들고 싶다면 그건 정말 힘들고 많이 불편할 거예요. 사람들에게도 그 점을 계속 상기시켜 줘야 해요. 직장에서 안전지대(comfort zone)에 머무르고 있다면 분명 실수를 하고 있는 거예요.
text_zh: 如果你想做出真正了不起的成绩，想要进入那1%的顶尖行列，那肯定会特别难，特别不舒服。你得经常提醒大家，如果在工作中感觉太舒适了，那绝对是走错路了。
text_es: Si quieres lograr algo realmente extraordinario, si quieres estar en el percentil 99 en cuanto a resultados, va a ser súper difícil. Te va a hacer sentir muy incómodo. Y tienes que recordarle a la gente que si alguna vez se encuentran en su zona de confort en el trabajo, definitivamente están cometiendo un error.
context: Lenny asks Matt about his philosophy that extraordinary results require extraordinary efforts. Matt explains that achieving exceptional outcomes - being in the 99th percentile - requires accepting that the work will be difficult and uncomfortable. He emphasizes that if someone finds themselves comfortable at work, they're likely not pushing hard enough to achieve extraordinary results.
vocabulary_highlights: 99th percentile, comfort zone, making a mistake

speaker: Matt MacInnis
text: The extraordinary effort thing is a reminder that it's supposed to be really fricking exhausting. It's supposed to be.
