So on Friday night, when you get hit with an escalation on Friday night, when you get sort of hit with a bunch of new bugs from someone in the engineering team that you've got a triage, those are the moments where great players and great teams are separated from good players and good teams.
text_ko: '엄청난 노력'이라는 얘기는 그 일이 정말 고되고 지치게 마련이라는 걸 상기시켜줘요. 그래야 해요. 그래서 금요일 밤에 에스컬레이션(escalation)이 들어오거나 엔지니어링팀(engineering team)에서 새 버그(bug)들이 몰려와서 트리아지(triage)를 해야 할 때가 바로 훌륭한 사람과 팀이 그저 괜찮은 사람과 팀과 갈리는 순간이에요.
text_zh: 超常努力这件事提醒我们，工作本来就应该累得要死，就是应该这样。所以周五晚上，当你突然遇到紧急情况需要处理，或者工程团队那边突然冒出一堆新的bug需要你去分类处理，这些时候就是区分顶尖选手和普通选手、顶尖团队和普通团队的关键时刻。
text_es: La cosa del esfuerzo extraordinario es un recordatorio de que se supone que tiene que ser súper agotador. Así es como debe ser. Entonces el viernes por la noche, cuando te cae una escalación, cuando te llueven un montón de bugs nuevos del equipo de ingeniería que tienes que priorizar, esos son los momentos donde se separan los jugadores y equipos extraordinarios de los que son solo buenos.
context: Matt continues explaining his extraordinary efforts philosophy by giving concrete examples. He describes how the work should feel exhausting and points to specific scenarios - like getting escalations on Friday nights or having to triage bugs - as the defining moments that separate great teams from merely good ones. These challenging moments are when superior performance is demonstrated.
vocabulary_highlights: really fricking exhausting, get hit with, triage

speaker: Matt MacInnis
text: It is really important to me that we feel that we've deliberately understaffed every project at the company. If you overstaff, you get politics, you get people working on things that are further down the priority list than necessary. That is poison. It's wasteful. It slows you down. It creates cruft.
text_ko: 회사의 모든 프로젝트에서 일부러 인력을 줄였다는 느낌이 정말 중요해요. 인력이 과다하면 정치적 문제도 생기고, 우선순위가 낮은 일에 사람들이 시간을 쓰게 되거든요. 그건 독이 되고, 낭비가 되고, 속도를 늦추고, 불필요한 것들이 쌓이게 해요.
text_zh: 对我来说特别重要的一点是，我们公司每个项目都要故意少配人手。如果人员冗余的话，就会产生办公室政治，大家就会去搞一些不那么重要的事情。这简直是毒药，既浪费资源，又拖慢进度，还会产生各种没用的东西。
text_es: Es súper importante para mí que sintamos que hemos dejado deliberadamente pocos recursos humanos en cada proyecto de la empresa. Si pones demasiada gente, empiezas a tener política interna, gente trabajando en cosas que están muy abajo en la lista de prioridades cuando no es necesario. Eso es veneno. Es un desperdicio. Te frena. Crea pura basura (cruft).
context: Matt explains his management philosophy about staffing projects. He advocates for deliberately understaffing rather than overstaffing because overstaffing leads to negative consequences like office politics and people working on lower-priority tasks. He uses the term 'cruft' to describe the unnecessary complexity and waste that comes from having too many people on a project.
vocabulary_highlights: deliberately understaffed, further down the priority list, creates cruft

speaker: Matt MacInnis
text: Fundamentally, the most selfish thing you can do is withhold feedback from someone. When you think a thought that would help someone improve and you avoid giving it to them because it would make you uncomfortable. Well, you're optimizing for your own comfort, and it's fundamentally selfish.
text_ko: 근본적으로, 누군가에게 피드백(feedback)을 주지 않는 게 가장 이기적인 행동이에요. 누군가가 발전하는 데 도움이 될 말이 떠올랐는데 내가 불편할까 봐 그걸 말하지 않는다면 자기 편안함만을 우선하는 거고, 결국 정말 이기적인 행동이에요.
text_zh: 说白了，最自私的事情就是不给别人反馈。你明明想到了能帮人家改进的点子，但因为怕自己不舒服就不说出来。这其实就是为了让自己舒服，本质上就是自私。
text_es: En el fondo, lo más egoísta que puedes hacer es no darle feedback a alguien. Cuando tienes una idea que podría ayudar a esa persona a mejorar y no se la das porque te va a resultar incómodo... bueno, estás priorizando tu propia comodidad, y eso es puro egoísmo.
context: Lenny mentions that Matt is a big fan of escalating issues, and Matt explains his philosophy on feedback. He argues that withholding helpful feedback from someone because it makes you uncomfortable is the most selfish behavior possible. This is because you're prioritizing your own comfort over helping someone else improve and grow professionally.
vocabulary_highlights: withhold feedback, optimizing for your own comfort, fundamentally selfish
topics: Leadership & Management, Communication Skills, Coaching & Development

speaker: Matt MacInnis
text: The purest form of ambition and most intense source of energy in the business is the founder CEO. Every next concentric circle of management beyond the founder CEO has the potential to be an order of magnitude drop off in intensity. That is fucking dangerous.
text_ko: 비즈니스에서는 야망의 가장 순수한 형태이자 에너지의 가장 강렬한 원천이 창업자 겸 CEO(founder CEO)예요. 창업자에서 바깥으로 이어지는 다음 동심원(concentric circle)에 속한 경영진은 에너지 강도가 한 차원, 심지어는 한 자릿수(즉 십배) 수준으로 떨어질 수 있어요. 그건 진짜 위험해요.
text_zh: 创始人CEO是公司里最纯粹的野心和最强的驱动力。离创始人CEO越远的那些管理层，他们的干劲可能会断崖式下跌。这他妈的太危险了。
text_es: La forma más pura de ambición y la fuente de energía más intensa en el negocio es el CEO fundador. Cada siguiente círculo concéntrico de gerencia más allá del CEO fundador tiene el potencial de ser una caída de intensidad de un orden de magnitud. Eso es jodidamente peligroso.
context: Matt discusses organizational dynamics and how intensity can diminish as you move away from the founder. He explains that founder CEOs typically have the highest level of ambition and energy, but each layer of management below them risks dramatically reducing that intensity - potentially by an order of magnitude. He sees this dilution of intensity as a serious threat to organizational performance.
vocabulary_highlights: purest form of ambition, concentric circle, order of magnitude drop off

speaker: Matt MacInnis
text: You don't really learn from your mistakes, you learn from your successes. Of course, you learn a bit from mistakes, but I do think that this is sort of feel good that it's like, 'Well, you didn't succeed, but at least you learned something.' I've learned so much more because I've seen success.
text_ko: 사실 실수에서 진짜 배우는 경우보다 성공에서 더 많이 배우는 편이에요. 물론 실수로부터 어느 정도는 배우지만, '성공하진 못했지만 적어도 뭔가 배웠으니 다행' 같은 위로의 느낌도 있는 것 같아요. 저는 성공을 직접 경험하면서 훨씬 더 많은 걸 배웠어요.
text_zh: 其实你真正学到东西不是从失败中，而是从成功中。当然，失败也能学到一点，但我觉得那种"虽然没成功，但至少学到了什么"的说法更多是自我安慰。我从成功的经历中学到的东西要多得多。
text_es: En realidad no aprendes tanto de tus errores, sino de tus éxitos. Claro, algo sí aprendes de los errores, pero creo que esto de "bueno, no te fue bien, pero al menos aprendiste algo" es como para consolarse. Yo he aprendido muchísimo más porque he visto el éxito de cerca.
context: Matt challenges the common Silicon Valley wisdom that failure is the best teacher. He argues that while people do learn from mistakes, they actually learn much more from experiencing success. He contrasts his nine years at his previous company Inkling (which struggled) with his time at the successful company Rippling, noting that observing what works right provides more valuable insights than seeing what goes wrong.
vocabulary_highlights: feel good, at least you learned something

speaker: Matt MacInnis
text: We talk in Silicon Valley about never quit, but that is complete absolute venture capital bullshit. The incentive of venture capitalist is to put money into your company and milk you dry. They never get their money back. There is no way for them to take that investment back.
text_ko: 실리콘밸리(Silicon Valley)에서는 '절대 포기하지 마라'고들 말하죠. 그런데 그건 벤처 투자자(venture capitalist)들의 완전한 헛소리예요. 벤처 투자자들의 인센티브(incentive)는 당신 회사에 돈을 넣고 다 쥐어짜서 빨아먹는 거예요. 그들은 절대 투자금을 돌려받지 못해요. 투자금을 회수할 방법이 전혀 없거든요.
text_zh: 我们在硅谷总说永不放弃，但这完全就是风投(venture capital)的扯淡。风投(venture capitalist)的动机就是往你公司砸钱，然后把你榨干。他们的钱根本收不回来，也没办法把投资撤回去。
text_es: En Silicon Valley siempre hablan de "nunca te rindas", pero eso es una completa mentira de los capitalistas de riesgo. El incentivo de los venture capitalists es meter plata en tu empresa y exprimirte hasta el último centavo. Nunca recuperan su dinero. No tienen manera de retirar esa inversión.
context: Matt challenges the popular Silicon Valley mentality of 'never quit' when discussing product-market fit and knowing when to shut down a startup. He argues this advice serves venture capitalists' interests rather than entrepreneurs' interests, since VCs can't get their money back once invested and benefit from founders continuing to try even when success is unlikely. This creates misaligned incentives between VCs and founders.
vocabulary_highlights: complete absolute venture capital bullshit, milk you dry

speaker: Matt Mochary
text: The biggest marker that I've seen between a botched layoff and a successful layoff is at the moment someone hears that they no longer have a job, did they hear it from their manager in a one-on-one? If that's when they heard it, it'll be okay. But if they heard it in an email, in a group chat, in any kind of thing where they were sitting next to or they're hearing it along with other people, it wasn't personalized, it wasn't one-on-one, that is terrible.
text_ko: 제가 본 가장 큰 차이는, 엉망으로 진행된 감원(botched layoff)과 잘된 감원(successful layoff)을 가르는 게 사람들이 '자신이 더 이상 직장이 없다는 소식'을 어떻게 들었느냐예요. 그 순간을 매니저가 일대일(one-on-one)로 직접 알려줬다면 괜찮아요. 그런데 이메일(email)이나 단체 채팅(group chat)으로, 다른 사람 옆에 앉아 있거나 다른 사람들과 동시에 같은 소식을 들었다면 — 개인화되지도 않았고 일대일도 아니었다면 — 정말 끔찍해요.
text_zh: 我发现裁员搞砸和裁员做得好之间最大的区别就是，员工听到自己被裁的那一刻是怎么听到的。如果是他们的直属领导单独一对一告诉他们的，那基本上就没什么大问题。但如果他们是通过邮件、群聊，或者和其他人一起听到消息的，没有个人化的沟通，不是一对一的，那就搞得很难看了。
text_es: La principal diferencia que he visto entre un despido mal manejado y uno exitoso es el momento en que alguien se entera de que ya no tiene trabajo: ¿se lo dijo su jefe cara a cara, en privado? Si fue así, todo estará bien. Pero si se enteró por email, en un chat grupal, o cualquier situación donde estaba junto a otras personas o lo escuchó al mismo tiempo que otros, sin que fuera personalizado, sin que fuera uno a uno, eso es terrible.
context: Lenny asks Matt about handling layoffs effectively, particularly in the context of recent tech industry layoffs. Matt explains the critical difference between successful and unsuccessful layoffs based on his experience coaching numerous CEOs through this process. He emphasizes that the method of delivery - whether personal and private versus impersonal and public - determines whether employees become angry and publicly criticize the company or accept the news more gracefully.
vocabulary_highlights: botched layoff, dehumanizing, didn't give a shit about me

speaker: Matt Mochary
text: I believe that fear is actually giving you bad advice and I think you're predicting that if you do this A will happen. Well, I'm predicting that if you do that, the exact opposite will happen. So, I'll tell you what, why don't we make a bet? This is very high stakes, why don't we pick something that's lower stakes?
text_ko: 사실 두려움이 잘못된 조언을 해주고 있다고 생각해요. 당신은 이걸 하면 A가 일어날 거라고 예측하는 거고, 저는 그 반대가 일어날 거라고 예측해요. 그럼 내기해볼까요? 이건 판이 너무 크니까 부담 덜한 걸로 하나 하죠.
text_zh: 我觉得恐惧其实在给你出坏主意，你现在预测如果这么做会发生A情况，但我预测的结果恰恰相反。这样吧，咱们打个赌怎么样？不过这事儿风险太大了，要不咱们先找个风险小点的事情试试？
text_es: Yo creo que el miedo te está dando muy malos consejos y me parece que tú estás pensando que si haces esto va a pasar A. Bueno, pues yo te digo que si haces eso, va a pasar exactamente lo contrario. Mira, ¿sabes qué? ¿Por qué no hacemos una apuesta? Esto tiene mucho riesgo, ¿por qué no mejor escogemos algo que tenga menos riesgo?
context: Lenny asks about the most common areas where successful founders struggle. Matt explains that fear is the primary obstacle, causing founders to avoid necessary but difficult actions. He describes his coaching method of challenging fear-based predictions by making bets with clients on lower-stakes situations to prove that fear often leads to incorrect assumptions about outcomes. This builds trust in the principle that fear gives bad advice.
vocabulary_highlights: high stakes, lower stakes

speaker: Matt Mochary
text: Then finally she said, 'I perceive you to be in anger.' So it's an I statement and it's simply what she's perceiving. There's no judgment. That was able to punch through my anger and then I woke up and went, oh, and then I stopped and just didn't act until I was able to shift out of anger.
text_ko: 마지막에 그녀가 "당신이 화가 나 있는 것 같아요"라고 말했어요. 그건 I 스테이트먼트(I statement)였고, 단순히 그녀가 그렇게 인지하고 있다는 표현이었어요. 판단이 전혀 들어 있지 않았어요. 그 말이 제 분노를 뚫고 들어왔고, 그제서야 정신이 들어 '아' 하고 멈췄어요. 그리고 제가 화에서 벗어날 수 있을 때까지 아무 행동도 하지 않았어요.
text_zh: 最后她说："我感觉你好像在生气。" 你看，这是一个"我"的表述，就是单纯说出她的感受，没有任何评判。这句话一下子就击中了我的愤怒情绪，让我突然清醒过来，意识到"哎呀，确实是这样"，然后我就停下来，什么都不做，直到自己从愤怒中走出来为止。
text_es: Entonces finalmente me dijo: "Percibo que estás enojado." O sea, usó una declaración en primera persona y simplemente describió lo que ella estaba viendo. Sin juzgar para nada. Eso logró atravesar mi enojo y entonces reaccioné como "ah, tienes razón," y me detuve y no hice nada hasta que pude salir de ese estado de enojo.
context: Lenny asks about giving feedback to someone who is experiencing anger or fear. Matt shares how he and his wife iterated on the language for pointing out when he was in an angry state. They discovered that using 'I perceive you to be in anger' works better than accusatory statements because it's non-judgmental and allows the person to recognize their emotional state without becoming more defensive.
vocabulary_highlights: punch through my anger, shift out of anger

speaker: Matt Mochary
text: What I do is I become their agent and I say, 'I want to help you discover what it is that your ideal role is, and I want to help you create it or land it.' I did that with him. I'm talking about active, and it doesn't take long. Maybe one to two hours of my time reaching out to people I know saying, 'Hey, I've got this great person.'
text_ko: 제가 하는 일은 그분들의 에이전트(agent)가 돼서 "당신의 이상적인 역할(ideal role)이 무엇인지 찾아드리고, 그 역할을 만들어 내거나 그 자리를 얻을 수 있게 도와드리고 싶어요"라고 말하는 거예요. 그분에게도 그렇게 도와드렸고요. 제가 말하는 건 적극적인 접근(active approach)인데, 오래 걸리지 않아요. 제가 아는 사람들한테 연락해서 "이 사람 정말 괜찮아요"라고 소개하는 데 제 시간 한두 시간 정도면 충분해요.
text_zh: 我就是当他们的代理人，我会跟他们说："我想帮你找到你理想的工作是什么样的，然后帮你争取到或者创造出这个机会。" 我就是这么帮他的。我说的是主动出击，其实也花不了多长时间，可能就花我一两个小时，联系我认识的人，跟他们说："嘿，我这儿有个特别棒的人。"
text_es: Lo que hago es convertirme en su agente y les digo: "Quiero ayudarte a descubrir cuál es tu puesto ideal, y quiero ayudarte a crearlo o conseguirlo." Eso fue lo que hice con él. Hablo de ser proactivo, y no lleva mucho tiempo. Quizás una o dos horas de mi tiempo contactando gente que conozco y diciéndoles: "Oye, tengo a esta persona buenísima."
context: Lenny asks about developing the skill of firing people effectively. Matt explains his approach of becoming an 'agent' for people he lets go - actively helping them find their next opportunity rather than just offering passive references. He emphasizes the difference between passive support (offering references if asked) versus active advocacy (proactively reaching out to contacts on their behalf), comparing it to how talent agents like Michael Ovitz work for their clients.
vocabulary_highlights: become their agent, land it, that's bullshit, that's passive

speaker: Matt Mochary
text: She separates the decision from the implementation, meaning she thinks about who is the stakeholder here that I'm solving for? And almost always in a company, you're solving for the customer. So, what would the customer want to see happen? That's the decision.
text_ko: 그녀는 결정(decision)과 실행(implementation)을 분리해요. 즉, "내가 해결하려는 이해관계자(stakeholder)가 누구지?"를 먼저 생각해요. 그리고 회사에서는 거의 항상 고객(customer)을 기준으로 해요. 그래서 고객이 어떤 결과를 보고 싶어할지를 생각하는 게 바로 결정이에요.
text_zh: 她把决策和执行分开来看，就是说她会想，这里的利益相关方(stakeholder)到底是谁？我到底在为谁解决问题？在公司里，十有八九你都是在为客户解决问题。所以客户希望看到什么结果？这就是决策的关键。
text_es: Ella separa la decisión de la ejecución, o sea, se pregunta ¿quién es realmente el stakeholder aquí para el que estoy resolviendo esto? Y casi siempre en una empresa, estás resolviendo para el cliente. Entonces, ¿qué querría ver el cliente que pase? Esa es la decisión.
context: Lenny asks about why managers struggle with firing people. Matt shares a framework from Wei Deng, CEO of Clipboard Health, about separating decisions from implementation. The decision should be based on what's best for the primary stakeholder (usually the customer), while implementation focuses on how to minimize harm to all affected parties. This helps managers overcome emotional barriers to necessary but difficult personnel decisions.
vocabulary_highlights: separates the decision from the implementation

speaker: Matt Mochary
text: It has to have a founder mentality person as the head of the team, someone who's willing to just break glass and just won't stop until they run through the brick wall. It's actually pretty easy to find founder mentality folks. You just literally go to the YC alumni list and the ones whose startups failed, perfect, they're available.
text_ko: 팀장은 창업가 마인드(founder mentality)를 가진 사람이어야 해요. 유리창을 깨서라도 밀어붙이고, 벽을 뚫을 때까지 절대 멈추지 않는 사람이어야 해요. 사실 그런 사람 찾는 건 의외로 쉬워요. 그냥 YC 동문 목록(Y Combinator alumni list)만 보면 돼요 — 스타트업이 실패한 사람들, 완벽해요. 구할 수 있어요.
text_zh: 团队负责人必须得有创始人心态(founder mentality)，就是那种敢拼敢闯、撞了南墙也不回头的人。其实找这种有创始人心态的人挺容易的，你直接去看YC孵化器的校友名单，那些创业失败的，完美，他们现在正好有空。
text_es: Tiene que haber una persona con mentalidad de fundador al frente del equipo, alguien que esté dispuesto a romper todo lo que haga falta y que no pare hasta tirar la pared de un cabezazo. En realidad es bastante fácil encontrar gente con mentalidad de fundador. Literalmente vas a la lista de ex-alumnos de YC y los que tuvieron startups que no funcionaron, perfecto, están disponibles.
context: Lenny asks about Matt's advice for innovating within larger companies. Matt explains his method of creating internal startup teams that operate like YC companies. He describes the type of leader needed - someone with 'founder mentality' who will persist through obstacles. He suggests recruiting from failed YC startups since these people have the right mindset but now want the stability of working within an established company.
vocabulary_highlights: founder mentality, break glass, run through the brick wall
topics: Leadership & Management, Starting a Company, Strategy & Planning

speaker: Matt Mochary
text: The key is to go and look at your day. How do you move into the zone of genius? It's not that you figure out what it is and do more of that, it's that you figure out what it isn't and eliminate that and then naturally, you'll be drawn toward what it is that you love.
text_ko: 핵심은 하루를 직접 들여다보는 거예요. 어떻게 지니어스 존(zone of genius)에 들어가냐고요? 그게 뭔지 찾아서 더 하려고 애쓰기보다, 무엇이 아닌지를 찾아서 제거하는 거예요. 그러면 자연스럽게 좋아하고 잘하는 쪽으로 끌리게 돼요.
text_zh: 关键是要回头看看你的日常工作。怎么才能进入你的天才区域(zone of genius)呢？不是说你要先搞清楚什么是你的强项然后多做这些，而是要先找出什么不是你的强项，把这些都砍掉，这样你自然就会被吸引到你真正热爱的事情上去。
text_es: Lo clave es que te pongas a analizar tu día a día. ¿Cómo llegas a esa zona de genialidad? No se trata de que descubras qué es lo tuyo y hagas más de eso, sino de que identifiques qué NO es lo tuyo y lo elimines, y entonces de forma natural te vas a ir inclinando hacia lo que realmente te apasiona.
context: Lenny asks about the energy audit concept that Matt teaches. Matt explains the four zones of work (incompetence, competence, excellence, and genius) and how to identify your zone of genius - work that you're uniquely good at and love doing. He emphasizes that the key to finding your zone of genius isn't adding more activities, but systematically eliminating energy-draining work that falls outside this zone.
vocabulary_highlights: zone of genius, naturally, you'll be drawn toward

speaker: Matt Mullenweg
text: If you were kind of inside baseball with WordPress, it's actually a lot of people who have been unhappy with me over the years. Previously, 1% of the world thought I was terrible and now I feel like it's up to four or 5%.
text_ko: WordPress 쪽 내부 사정(inside baseball)을 좀 아신다면, 사실 수년 동안 저에게 불만을 가진 사람들이 꽤 많았어요. 예전에는 전 세계의 1% 정도만 저를 형편없다고 생각했는데, 요즘은 4~5%까지 늘어난 것 같아요.
text_zh: 如果你对WordPress内部情况比较了解的话，其实这些年来对我不满的人挺多的。以前全世界只有1%的人觉得我很糟糕，现在我感觉已经涨到4%、5%了。
text_es: Si estabas al tanto de lo que pasaba internamente en WordPress, en realidad hay mucha gente que ha estado molesta conmigo a lo largo de los años. Antes, el 1% del mundo pensaba que era un desastre y ahora siento que ya subió al cuatro o 5%.
context: Lenny asks Matt about how he deals with the negative sentiment from people who now see him as controversial due to the WP Engine dispute. Matt explains that while many people think he was universally beloved before this controversy, there have actually been critics within the WordPress community for years over various decisions like introducing new features. He's putting the current criticism in perspective by noting it's still a small percentage of people overall.
vocabulary_highlights: inside baseball, up to four or 5%

speaker: Matt Mullenweg
text: Since 2019, WP Engine has kind of changed a bit. They started using the trademark, they're offering something called WordPress. They're referred to it as like a bastardized hacked up version of it. It's diluting our brand.
text_ko: 2019년 이후로 WP Engine이 좀 달라졌어요. 상표(trademark)를 쓰기 시작했고, 워드프레스(WordPress)라는 걸 서비스로 내놓더라고요. 사람들은 그걸 원형을 훼손한, 엉망으로 뜯어고친 변형판이라고 부르더라고요. 그래서 우리 브랜드가 희석되고 있어요.
text_zh: 从2019年开始，WP Engine这家公司有点变味儿了。他们开始打我们商标的擦边球，搞了个什么WordPress的服务。说白了就是把我们的东西改得乱七八糟的，完全是个四不像的山寨版。这不是在砸我们品牌的招牌吗。
text_es: Desde 2019, WP Engine como que ha cambiado un poco. Empezaron a usar la marca registrada, están ofreciendo algo que llaman WordPress. Se refieren a eso como una versión bastardizada y pirateada. Está diluyendo nuestra marca.
context: Lenny asks Matt to explain the high-level overview of what's happening with WP Engine. Matt describes how WP Engine was acquired by private equity firm Silver Lake in 2019, and since then has been using WordPress trademarks inappropriately while offering a modified version of WordPress that removes key features like post revisions to save money. This creates brand confusion and dilutes the WordPress trademark.
vocabulary_highlights: bastardized hacked up version, diluting our brand

speaker: Matt Mullenweg
text: If you're really open and open source, sometimes you have to stand up the bullies and you have to fight to protect your open source ideals. Otherwise people could take advantage of it in a way that ultimately can destroy everything you've created.
text_ko: 정말로 개방적이고 오픈 소스(open source)라면, 때로는 횡포를 부리는 사람들에게 단호히 맞서 싸워서 그 오픈 소스 가치를 지켜야 해요. 안 그러면 사람들이 그걸 부당하게 이용해서 결국 지금까지 쌓아온 모든 걸 망가뜨릴 수 있어요.
text_zh: 如果你真的要做开放和开源(open source)，有时候就得跟那些欺负人的较较真，得为了保护你的开源理念去争取。不然的话，别人就会钻空子，最后可能把你辛辛苦苦建起来的东西全给毁了。
text_es: Si realmente estás comprometido con el código abierto (open source), a veces tienes que plantarles cara a los abusivos y luchar para proteger tus ideales de código abierto. Si no, la gente puede aprovecharse de una manera que al final puede destruir todo lo que has construido.
context: Matt explains why he took a confrontational approach with WP Engine despite his usual collaborative style. He's addressing criticism that he's become mean or aggressive, arguing that protecting open source principles sometimes requires standing up to companies that would exploit the open nature of these projects. He believes that failing to defend against such exploitation could ultimately harm the entire open source ecosystem he's spent decades building.
vocabulary_highlights: stand up the bullies, take advantage of it

speaker: Matt Mullenweg
text: A lie gets around the world seven times before the truth has time to get out of bed.
text_ko: 거짓말은 진실이 침대에서 나오기도 전에 이미 세상을 일곱 번이나 돈다고 해요.
text_zh: 假消息满天飞的时候，真相还没来得及澄清呢。
text_es: Una mentira ya le ha dado siete vueltas al mundo mientras la verdad todavía se está levantando de la cama.
context: Lenny asks why so many people view Matt as the bad guy in the WP Engine controversy. Matt responds with this classic saying to explain how misinformation can spread much faster than corrections on social media. He's suggesting that false narratives about the situation have gained more traction than the actual facts, particularly on platforms like Twitter where controversial content gets promoted by algorithms.
vocabulary_highlights: gets around the world, get out of bed

speaker: Matt Mullenweg
text: Don't just build a product, build a movement. And to the extent that we've been successful, I think it's that we give people something to believe in, a philosophy, a worldview.
text_ko: 그냥 제품만 만들지 말고, 무브먼트(movement)를 만들어야 해요. 우리가 어느 정도 성공할 수 있었던 건 사람들이 믿을 수 있는 무언가, 즉 하나의 철학이나 세계관을 제시해 줬기 때문이라고 생각해요.
text_zh: 不要只是做产品，要做一场运动。我觉得我们之前成功的原因，就是给了大家一个信念，一套理念，一种世界观。
text_es: No se trata solo de crear un producto, sino de crear un movimiento. Y en la medida en que hemos tenido éxito, creo que es porque les damos a las personas algo en lo que creer, una filosofía, una forma de ver el mundo.
context: Lenny asks Matt about lessons learned from building one of the most successful online communities around WordPress. Matt shares his core philosophy for community building, explaining that successful projects need more than just utility - they need to inspire people with a deeper purpose and philosophy. He attributes WordPress's success to giving people open source ideals to believe in, not just software to use.
vocabulary_highlights: build a movement, to the extent that, something to believe in

speaker: Matt Mullenweg
text: It's not just the software, it's also like: how are the meetups? How are people getting together? What events are you running? Are there forums? How do people contribute? Is there office hours or town halls?
text_ko: 단순히 소프트웨어만의 문제가 아니에요. 밋업(meetups)은 어떤가요? 사람들이 어떻게 모이나요? 어떤 이벤트를 운영하고 있나요? 포럼(forums)은 있나요? 사람들은 어떻게 기여하나요? 오피스 아워(office hours)나 타운홀(town halls)은 있나요?
text_zh: 不光是软件本身的问题，还有比如说：线下聚会(meetup)办得怎么样？大家平时怎么聚在一起交流？你们都搞什么活动？有没有论坛？大家是怎么参与贡献的？有没有答疑时间(office hours)或者全员大会(town hall)这些？
text_es: No es solo el software, también es como: ¿qué tal están los meetups? ¿Cómo se está juntando la gente? ¿Qué eventos están organizando? ¿Hay foros? ¿Cómo contribuye la gente? ¿Tienen office hours o town halls?
context: Matt continues explaining his community-building philosophy, emphasizing that successful open source projects require much more than just good software. He's describing the comprehensive ecosystem needed around a product - events, forums, contribution opportunities, and regular communication channels. This holistic approach to community building has been key to WordPress's success in creating engaged contributors and users.
vocabulary_highlights: office hours, town halls

speaker: Matthew Dicks
text: Everyone loves the word storytelling in business. It's a huge buzzword. They love to think of themselves as storytellers, but when they come to me, they don't really want to be storytellers. Because to be a storyteller means you have to separate yourself from the herd, and in their mind, that risks them getting picked off, right? Getting picked off by some predator. But the alternative is you're in the herd, which means you're forgettable.
text_ko: 비즈니스에서 '스토리텔링 (storytelling)'이라는 말을 다들 좋아해요. 큰 버즈워드 (buzzword)이기도 하고요. 스스로를 스토리텔러라고 생각하는 걸 좋아하지만, 막상 제게 찾아오는 사람들은 진짜 스토리텔러가 되고 싶어하지 않아요. 스토리텔러가 된다는 건 무리에서 자신을 분리해야 한다는 뜻이라, 그럼 표적이 될 위험이 있다고 생각하거든요 — 어떤 포식자한테 잡아먹히는 것처럼요. 그런데 반대로 무리 속에 남아 있으면 눈에 띄지 않아서 금방 잊혀지게 돼요.
text_zh: 现在做生意的人都特别爱说"讲故事"这个词，简直是个超级热门词汇(buzzword)。他们都喜欢把自己当成讲故事的人，但真找到我的时候，其实他们根本不想当什么讲故事的人。因为要想讲好故事，你就得从人群中脱颖而出，但在他们心里，这样做风险太大，容易被人盯上，对吧？就像被捕食者盯上一样。但反过来说，如果你就混在人群里，那你就是个可有可无、没人记得住的角色。
text_es: A todo el mundo le encanta la palabra storytelling en los negocios. Es un término súper de moda. Les gusta pensar que son storytellers, pero cuando vienen a verme, en realidad no quieren serlo. Porque ser un storyteller significa que tienes que separarte del rebaño, y en su mente, eso los pone en riesgo de que los cacen, ¿no? Que los agarre algún depredador. Pero la alternativa es quedarte en el rebaño, lo cual significa que eres olvidable.
context: Lenny asks Matthew about the risks of being too safe and generic in business communication. Matthew explains the paradox many business professionals face with storytelling - while everyone claims to want to be a storyteller, most are actually afraid to stand out from their competitors. He describes the tension between playing it safe (staying in the herd) versus taking the risk of being memorable through authentic storytelling.
vocabulary_highlights: separate yourself from the herd, getting picked off, in the herd

speaker: Matthew Dicks
text: Every story essentially about a singular moment. I call it five seconds. It can be one second honestly. It's a moment of either transformation, meaning I'm telling you a story about how I once used to be one kind of person and now I'm a new kind of person. Or more common is realization. Which is I used to think something and then some stuff happened and now I think a new thing.
text_ko: 결국 모든 이야기는 한 순간에 관한 거예요. 저는 그걸 '5초'라고 부르는데요. 솔직히 말하면 1초일 수도 있어요. 그 순간은 두 가지예요. 하나는 변화의 순간이에요 — 예전에는 이런 사람이었는데 지금은 다른 사람이 됐다는 이야기죠. 더 흔한 건 깨달음이에요. 예전에는 이렇게 생각했는데 어떤 일이 일어나서 지금은 다르게 생각하게 됐다는 경우예요.
text_zh: 其实每个故事的核心就是那关键的一瞬间，我叫它"五秒钟时刻"，说实话有时候一秒钟就够了。这个时刻要么是转变——就是我要跟你讲我以前是什么样的人，现在变成了什么样的人。要么更常见的是顿悟——就是我以前是这么想的，然后发生了一些事，现在我的想法完全不一样了。
text_es: Toda historia básicamente trata de un momento único. Yo le digo los cinco segundos. Puede ser un segundo, la verdad. Es un momento de transformación, o sea, te estoy contando una historia de cómo antes era un tipo de persona y ahora soy otra. O lo más común es la realización. Que es: antes pensaba algo, luego pasaron cosas, y ahora pienso algo diferente.
context: Lenny asks Matthew about his concept that all good stories center around one five-second moment. Matthew explains that every compelling story is built around a singular moment of either transformation (becoming a different type of person) or realization (changing what you think about something). This moment is what the entire story should build toward, with 98% of the story serving as context to bring that crucial moment into sharp focus for the audience.
vocabulary_highlights: singular moment, moment of transformation, moment of realization

speaker: Matthew Dicks
text: The dinner test is the idea that when you're telling a story in a formal way, if you're performing on a stage or delivering a keynote or even delivering a pitch to entrepreneurs or a sales pitch, essentially the story that you're telling should be very closely related to the story you would tell someone if you were having dinner.
text_ko: 디너 테스트(dinner test)는 공식적인 자리에서 스토리를 전할 때—무대에서 발표를 하거나 기조연설(keynote)을 하거나 창업가들에게 피치(pitch)를 하거나 영업 피치(sales pitch)를 할 때조차—사실상 그 이야기는 누군가와 저녁 식사하면서 편하게 나눌 이야기와 거의 같아야 한다는 생각이에요.
text_zh: 晚餐测试(dinner test)这个概念是说，当你正式讲故事的时候，不管是在台上演讲、做主题发言(keynote)，还是向创业者路演(pitch)或者做销售展示，你讲的故事本质上应该和你跟朋友吃饭聊天时讲的故事差不多。
text_es: La prueba de la cena es la idea de que cuando estás contando una historia de manera formal, ya sea que estés presentando en un escenario o dando una charla magistral (keynote) o incluso haciendo un pitch a emprendedores o una presentación de ventas, básicamente la historia que estás contando debería ser muy parecida a la historia que le contarías a alguien si estuvieras cenando con esa persona.
context: Lenny asks Matthew about his checklist for what makes a good story. Matthew explains the 'dinner test' - one of his key criteria for effective storytelling. The dinner test means that formal presentations should sound like slightly elevated versions of natural conversation, avoiding artificial performance elements like unattributed dialogue or dramatic sound effects that would seem bizarre in normal conversation.
vocabulary_highlights: dinner test, closely related, slightly elevated

speaker: Matthew Dicks
text: Stakes are essentially what your audience should be worried about, what they should be wanting for you, what they should be concerned about, what they should be wondering about. If your audience isn't wondering what you're about to say, they're no longer listening to you. And you have to internalize that in a deep and fundamental way.
text_ko: 여기서 '중요 쟁점(stakes)'은 본질적으로 청중(audience)이 걱정해야 할 것, 당신에게 바라는 것, 신경 써야 할 것, 궁금해해야 할 것을 말해요. 청중이 다음에 당신이 뭘 말할지 궁금해하지 않으면, 그들은 더 이상 당신의 말을 듣고 있는 게 아니에요. 이걸 깊고 근본적으로 내 것으로 만들어야 해요.
text_zh: 关键点(stakes)其实就是你要让听众担心的事情，让他们为你着急，让他们关注，让他们好奇。如果听众对你接下来要说什么一点都不好奇，那他们根本就不会认真听你讲。这个道理你得真正理解透，从骨子里明白这一点。
text_es: Las consecuencias son básicamente lo que tu audiencia debería preocuparles, lo que deberían estar deseando para ti, lo que debería inquietarles, sobre lo que deberían estar preguntándose. Si tu audiencia no se está preguntando qué vas a decir después, ya no te están escuchando. Y tienes que interiorizar eso de manera profunda y fundamental.
context: Lenny asks Matthew to explain what stakes are and why they're important in storytelling. Matthew explains that stakes are what keep audiences engaged by giving them something to worry about or wonder about. He emphasizes that business professionals often mistakenly assume people want to hear what they have to say, when in reality, speakers must constantly work to maintain audience attention through creating uncertainty and concern about what happens next.
vocabulary_highlights: internalize that in a deep and fundamental way, verbal detritus

speaker: Matthew Dicks
text: If you don't tell stories as part of your business, whether you're looking for investment, or speaking to your people, or speaking to customers, or clients, anything, if you're not telling stories, the good news is, you're just like everybody else. The bad news is, you're mediocre just like everybody else. You're in a lane that everyone else is in, which means that you're going to be forgettable.
text_ko: 사업에서 스토리텔링(storytelling)을 하지 않으면, 투자를 구하든 직원들에게 말하든 고객이나 클라이언트와 이야기하든—어떤 상황에서건 이야기를 하지 않는다면 좋은 소식은 다른 사람들과 다를 바 없다는 거예요. 나쁜 소식은 그만큼 평범하다는 뜻이에요. 결국 모두가 있는 같은 영역에 서 있게 돼서 기억에 남지 않게 돼요.
text_zh: 如果你做生意不会讲故事，不管是找投资、跟员工说话、还是面对客户，什么场合都不讲故事的话，好消息是你跟大家都一样；坏消息是你跟大家一样平庸。你走的路跟所有人都一样，这就意味着你会被人忘记。
text_es: Si no usas historias en tu negocio, ya sea que busques inversión, que hables con tu equipo, con clientes, lo que sea, si no cuentas historias, la buena noticia es que eres igual que todos los demás. La mala noticia es que eres del montón, igual que todos. Estás en el mismo carril que todo el mundo, lo que significa que van a olvidarse de ti.
context: Lenny asks Matthew about the benefits of learning storytelling skills versus the problems people face if they don't develop these abilities. Matthew explains the cost of not using storytelling in business - while it feels safe to communicate the same way as everyone else, this approach makes you completely forgettable. He contrasts this with the alternative of using stories to stand out and be memorable, even though it requires more courage.
vocabulary_highlights: you're in a lane, mediocre just like everybody else

speaker: Matthew Dicks
text: I have this tool I use with corporate folks called, a personal interest inventory. It is a list of all the things that you should be saying about yourself in clever and strategic ways that I teach. Each one of them has an addressable market. So how many people could this potentially hit? And then the intensity of the connection.
text_ko: 회사 분들과 함께 쓸 때 제가 사용하는 도구가 하나 있어요. ‘개인 관심 목록(personal interest inventory)’이라고 부르는데, 제가 가르치는 방식대로 자신에 대해 영리하고 전략적으로 말해야 할 것들을 모두 정리한 목록이에요. 각 항목마다 도달 가능한 시장(addressable market)이 있어서, 이게 잠재적으로 몇 명에게 닿을 수 있는지와 그 연결의 강도가 얼마나 되는지를 따져보는 거예요.
text_zh: 我有个工具专门用来跟企业高管们一起用的，叫个人兴趣清单(personal interest inventory)。就是把你应该怎么巧妙地、有策略地介绍自己的那些点都列出来，我会教你怎么说。每一个点都有它的目标受众(addressable market)。你想想看，这能影响到多少人？还有就是这种连接的强度有多深。
text_es: Tengo una herramienta que uso con la gente de las empresas que se llama inventario de intereses personales (personal interest inventory). Es una lista de todas las cosas que deberías estar diciendo de ti mismo de manera inteligente y estratégica, eso es lo que enseño. Cada una de esas cosas tiene un mercado al que puedes dirigirte. Entonces, ¿a cuánta gente podría llegar esto potencialmente? Y después está la intensidad de esa conexión.
context: Lenny asks Matthew about his advice to make business stories more personal. Matthew introduces his 'personal interest inventory' concept - a strategic approach to sharing personal details that help people connect with you. He explains how different personal attributes have varying 'addressable markets' (how many people can relate) and connection intensity (how strongly people who share that trait will connect with you), helping professionals decide which personal elements to strategically include in their communication.
vocabulary_highlights: personal interest inventory, addressable market, intensity of the connection

speaker: Maya Prohovnik
speaker_expertise: Product Management, User Experience, Growth Strategy
text: We were obsessed with reducing friction, this was our constant battle. And so we hired a couple of college interns and we brought them in and we were like, people are going to push this magical one button in the Anchor app and they're going to say, I want to distribute my podcast, and your job is going to be to do all that same manual stuff manually, but to them it's going to feel magical and it happened automatically.
text_ko: 우리는 마찰(friction)을 줄이는 데 집착했어요. 그게 늘 우리의 싸움이었죠. 그래서 대학생 인턴 몇 명을 고용해 데려왔어요. 그리고 '사람들이 앵커 앱(Anchor app)의 마법 같은 버튼 하나를 누르고 “내 팟캐스트를 배포하고 싶어요”라고 하면, 너희는 그 모든 수작업을 대신 해주면 된다. 사용자들에겐 이게 자동으로 된 것처럼, 마법처럼 느껴질 거다'라고 말했어요.
text_zh: 我们当时就是死磅着要减少用户的操作难度，这是我们一直在攻克的难题。所以我们就招了几个大学实习生过来，跟他们说，用户在Anchor应用里只要按一个神奇的按钮，说"我要分发我的播客"，然后你们的工作就是在后台手动把那些繁琐的活儿都给干了，但对用户来说感觉就像变魔术一样，一切都是自动完成的。
text_es: Estábamos obsesionados con eliminar fricciones, esa era nuestra batalla constante. Entonces contratamos a un par de becarios universitarios y cuando llegaron les dijimos: la gente va a tocar este botón mágico en la app de Anchor y va a decir "quiero distribuir mi podcast", y su trabajo va a ser hacer toda esa misma tarea manual a mano, pero para ellos va a sentirse mágico, como si hubiera pasado automáticamente.
context: Maya is sharing an early Anchor story about how they solved podcast distribution challenges. At the time, distributing podcasts to platforms like Apple Podcasts was extremely technical and difficult for creators - requiring Apple IDs, understanding RSS feeds, and dealing with technical hurdles. Maya explains how they created what appeared to be an automated solution by having college interns manually handle all the technical distribution work behind the scenes, making it feel seamless for users.
vocabulary_highlights: obsessed with reducing friction, magical one button, feel magical and it happened automatically
topics: Product Management, Starting a Company, Strategy & Planning

speaker: Maya Prohovnik
speaker_expertise: Product Management, User Experience, Growth Strategy
text: I think data is amazing and I'm like, we have such an incredible insights team at Spotify, both my insights team and then the broader one. I think we are so lucky and we have so much knowledge about our users and different cohorts and what people need and what they're missing, and so I think that's extremely valuable. I think where people get into trouble is when they think that they can rely solely on the data.
text_ko: 저는 데이터가 정말 놀랍다고 생각해요. 그리고 우리 스포티파이에 인사이트 팀(insights team)이 정말 대단하다고 느껴요 — 제 인사이트 팀도 있고, 더 큰 조직 차원의 팀도 있고요. 우리가 참 운이 좋다고 생각해요. 사용자들에 대해, 다양한 코호트(cohorts)별로 사람들이 무엇을 필요로 하고 무엇이 부족한지에 대해 정말 많은 지식을 가지고 있고, 그게 엄청난 가치라고 봐요. 사람들이 곤란해지는 건 데이터를 전적으로, 오로지 데이터에만 의존할 수 있다고 생각할 때예요.
text_zh: 我觉得数据真的太厉害了，我们Spotify的洞察团队简直不要太强，不管是我自己的团队还是整个大团队。我们真的太幸运了，对用户了解得特别透彻，各种用户群体(cohorts)都摸得很清楚，知道大家需要什么、缺什么，这真的是超级宝贵的资源。但我觉得问题就出在，有些人以为光靠数据就能搞定一切，这就容易出事了。
text_es: Creo que los datos son increíbles y es que tenemos un equipo de insights súper bueno en Spotify, tanto mi equipo como el más amplio. Creo que tenemos muchísima suerte y sabemos un montón sobre nuestros usuarios y los diferentes segmentos, qué necesita la gente y qué les falta, entonces eso me parece súper valioso. Pero creo que donde la gente se mete en problemas es cuando piensan que se pueden basar únicamente en los datos.
context: Lenny asks Maya about finding the balance between being data-driven versus gut-driven in product decisions, noting this is something many product leaders struggle with. Maya is explaining her philosophy on using data effectively while warning against over-reliance on data alone. She advocates for using data as one input among many in the creative product development process rather than as the sole decision-making framework.
vocabulary_highlights: get into trouble, rely solely on
topics: Product Management, Decision Making, Leadership & Management

speaker: Maya Prohovnik
speaker_expertise: Product Management, User Experience, Growth Strategy
text: I think something that I've had to learn is that being gut driven isn't the same as just saying to people, I told you or I believe this, so you have to do it. There really is an art I think to balancing that. And I think that what I try to do is always still as objectively as possible explain why my gut is feeling that way.
text_ko: 제가 배워야 했던 것 중 하나는, 직감(gut-driven)에 따라 움직인다는 게 단순히 '내가 옳았잖아요'라며 사람들에게 '그러니까 그대로 해요'라고 강요하는 것과는 다르다는 점이에요. 그 균형을 잡는 건 정말 묘한 감각이 필요해요. 그래서 저는 항상 가능한 한 객관적으로 제 직감이 왜 그런지 설명하려고 해요.
text_zh: 我觉得我学到的一点就是，凭直觉做决策不等于直接跟人说"我早就告诉你了"或者"我就是这么想的，你必须照做"。在这方面真的需要平衡的艺术。我现在尽量做的就是，还是要尽可能客观地解释为什么我的直觉是这样的。
text_es: Creo que algo que he tenido que aprender es que dejarse llevar por la intuición no es lo mismo que simplemente decirle a la gente "yo te dije" o "yo creo esto, así que tienes que hacerlo". Realmente hay todo un arte en encontrar ese equilibrio. Y lo que trato de hacer es siempre explicar de la forma más objetiva posible por qué mi intuición me dice eso.
context: Maya continues discussing how to balance gut instinct with data in product decisions, specifically addressing the challenge of leading in a large organization. She's explaining how being gut-driven requires more sophistication when you need to influence many stakeholders who aren't on your immediate team. Maya emphasizes that gut instinct must be communicated with objective reasoning and supporting evidence to be effective in larger organizational contexts.
vocabulary_highlights: there really is an art, as objectively as possible
topics: Leadership & Management, Decision Making, Communication Skills

speaker: Maya Prohovnik
speaker_expertise: Product Management, User Experience, Growth Strategy
text: I think you really have to be able to tell the signal through the noise, and even if you've got lots of vocal users asking for something, we used to have this rule, the 80/20 rule, where it's like you can't just build for that 20, I don't think we made this up by the way. I think this is a common thing, but we'd always refer to it and say, we want to be building for the 80%, and even though the 20% are going to be more vocal, that's just going to get you deeper into that hole of that problem of you're not really building for everyone.
text_ko: 정말로 노이즈 속에서 신호(signal through the noise)를 가려낼 줄 알아야 해요. 목소리 큰 사용자들이 많이 뭔가를 요청하더라도요. 예전부터 우리는 80/20 규칙(80/20 rule)을 갖고 있었는데, 그 규칙은 '그 20%만을 위해 만들 수 없다'는 뜻이에요. 참고로 이건 우리가 새로 만든 얘기가 아니라 다들 갖고 있는 생각인 것 같아요. 그래서 항상 그걸 기준으로 삼아서 '우리는 80%를 위해 만들어야 한다'고 말했어요. 20%가 더 시끄럽다고 거기에만 신경 쓰다 보면 오히려 문제의 구멍에 더 깊이 빠져서 결국 모두를 위한 제품을 만들지 못하게 돼요.
text_zh: 我觉得你得能够从噪音中找到真正的信号，就算有很多用户在那儿大声要求什么功能，我们以前有个规矩，就是二八定律(80/20 rule)，你不能只为那20%的人做产品。顺便说一句，这不是我们发明的，这应该是个常识吧。但我们总是会提到这个，说我们要为80%的用户做产品，虽然那20%的用户声音更大，但如果你只听他们的，只会让你越陷越深，到头来你做出来的产品根本不是给所有人用的。
text_es: Creo que realmente tienes que saber separar lo importante del ruido, y aunque tengas muchos usuarios que se quejan pidiendo algo, nosotros teníamos esta regla, la regla del 80/20, donde no puedes construir solo para ese 20%, y por cierto, no creo que se nos haya ocurrido a nosotros. Creo que es algo común, pero siempre la mencionábamos y decíamos, queremos construir para el 80%, y aunque ese 20% va a hacer más ruido, eso solo te va a meter más profundo en ese hoyo de ese problema de que en realidad no estás construyendo para todos.
context: Lenny asks Maya about the difficult decision to change Anchor from version 1.0 to 2.0 despite having users who loved the existing product. Maya is explaining the challenge of making strategic product decisions when you have satisfied but vocal users who represent a minority. She's describing how they learned to distinguish between feedback from power users versus the broader market they wanted to serve, emphasizing the importance of building for mainstream adoption rather than just the most engaged current users.
vocabulary_highlights: tell the signal through the noise, deeper into that hole
topics: Product Management, Strategy & Planning, Decision Making

speaker: Maya Prohovnik
speaker_expertise: Product Management, User Experience, Growth Strategy
text: I think you really have to stick to it and it's really hard, but you have to keep pivoting to get to where you want to be. Kill your darlings. I love that phrase, I use it all the time.
text_ko: 정말 끝까지 밀고 나가야 해요. 진짜 힘들지만 원하는 곳에 가려면 계속 피벗(pivoting)해 가며 방향을 조정해야 해요. 애정 있는 아이디어도 과감히 버려야 해요 (Kill your darlings). 그 표현 정말 좋아해요, 저도 항상 써요.
text_zh: 我觉得你真的得坚持下去，虽然特别难，但你必须不断调整方向(pivot)才能到达你想要的地方。要舍得放弃心爱的项目，我特别喜欢这个说法，经常用。
text_es: Creo que realmente tienes que ser constante y es súper difícil, pero hay que seguir adaptándose para llegar donde quieres estar. Mata a tus niños bonitos (kill your darlings). Me encanta esa frase, la uso todo el tiempo.
context: Maya and Lenny are discussing the challenge of having a product that's working but not achieving massive scale. Maya is explaining the importance of staying committed to your larger mission and vision, even when it means making difficult decisions to change things that are currently working. She references the common creative writing advice about 'killing your darlings' - being willing to cut things you love if they don't serve the bigger picture.
vocabulary_highlights: keep pivoting, kill your darlings
topics: Strategy & Planning, Starting a Company, Decision Making

speaker: Maya Prohovnik
speaker_expertise: Product Management, User Experience, Growth Strategy
text: I still don't know how many people know this. I think people think that we had some secret backdoor deal with Apple for distribution, but we just had college students making Apple podcast accounts and then submitting hundreds of thousands of podcasts through these accounts, and I think that was a really big part of why we got so much hosting market share so quickly because it was such an insane benefit over the other platforms which otherwise had been commoditized at that point.
text_ko: 이 사실을 얼마나 많은 사람이 알고 있는지는 아직 잘 모르겠어요. 사람들은 우리가 유통을 위해 Apple과 은밀한 백도어 거래(backdoor deal)를 한 것처럼 생각하는 것 같은데, 실제로는 대학생들이 Apple 팟캐스트 계정(Apple podcast accounts)을 만들어 그 계정들로 수십만 개의 팟캐스트를 제출했을 뿐이에요. 그게 당시 다른 플랫폼들이 이미 상품화(commoditized)돼 있던 상황에서 비교할 수 없을 만큼 큰 이점이었기 때문에 우리가 그렇게 빨리 호스팅 시장 점유율(hosting market share)을 많이 확보할 수 있었던 큰 이유 중 하나였다고 생각해요.
text_zh: 我觉得知道这件事的人还不多。大家可能以为我们跟苹果有什么私下的分发协议，其实根本不是这样的。我们就是找了一堆大学生去注册苹果播客账号，然后通过这些账号提交了几十万个播客，我觉得这就是我们能这么快拿到这么大市场份额的关键原因，因为这个优势太明显了，而其他平台那时候已经没什么差异化了，都差不多。
text_es: Todavía no sé cuánta gente sabe esto. Creo que la gente piensa que teníamos algún acuerdo por debajo de la mesa con Apple para la distribución, pero simplemente teníamos estudiantes universitarios creando cuentas de podcast de Apple y luego subiendo cientos de miles de podcasts a través de esas cuentas, y creo que eso fue una parte súper importante de por qué conseguimos tanto market share de hosting tan rápido porque era una ventaja brutal comparado con las otras plataformas que ya se habían commoditizado para ese momento.
context: Maya is elaborating on the earlier story about Anchor's unscalable solution for podcast distribution. She explains how they gained competitive advantage by making distribution appear automated when it was actually manual work done by interns. This created a remarkable user experience that drove word-of-mouth growth and helped them capture significant market share in podcast hosting, as competitors were offering similar technical features but without the ease-of-use advantage.
vocabulary_highlights: secret backdoor deal, insane benefit, had been commoditized
topics: Growth & Marketing, Starting a Company, Product Management

speaker: Mayur Kamat
speaker_expertise: Product Management, Growth Strategy, User Experience
text: My, probably, most spectacular failure was, I was the first PM on Hangouts. We had thousands of people working for me. We had entire power of Google. We had Larry literally sitting with us saying we can do anything we want Chrome to do and we still didn't manage to build a great messaging product.
text_ko: 제가 아마도 가장 큰 실패 중 하나는, 제가 처음으로 Hangouts의 PM이었을 때예요. 저희는 수천 명의 사람들이 저를 위해 일하고 있었고, Google의 모든 힘을 가지고 있었어요. Larry가 저희와 함께 앉아 'Chrome이 원하는 건 뭐든지 할 수 있다'고 말했는데도, 결국 훌륭한 메시징 제품을 만들지 못했어요.
text_zh: 我最惨痛的失败经历，应该就是我做Hangouts第一任产品经理(PM)的时候。我手下有几千号人，整个Google的资源都给我们用，Larry本人就坐在我们旁边，说Chrome想怎么改都行，结果我们还是没做出一个像样的聊天产品。
text_es: Mi fracaso más espectacular, probablemente, fue cuando fui el primer PM de Hangouts. Tenía miles de personas trabajando conmigo. Teníamos todo el poder de Google detrás. Larry literalmente se sentaba con nosotros diciéndonos que podíamos hacer lo que quisiéramos con Chrome y aun así no logramos crear un buen producto de mensajería.
context: Lenny asks Mayur about failures in his career. Mayur shares his experience as the first product manager on Google Hangouts, which despite having massive resources and direct support from Google's leadership, failed to become a successful messaging product. He explains this as his most significant product failure, highlighting how even with unlimited resources, product success isn't guaranteed.
vocabulary_highlights: spectacular failure, entire power of, literally sitting with us

speaker: Mayur Kamat
speaker_expertise: Product Management, Growth Strategy, User Experience
text: The challenge with being a product manager is, everybody thinks they can do the job. Anybody who uses the product thinks they have ideas, so at some point in time, you're like, "What is my discipline? What is my science?" The moment you build experimentation, you've now made it scientific.
text_ko: 프로덕트 매니저(product manager)로 일하면서 겪는 어려움은, 다들 그 일을 할 수 있다고 생각한다는 점이에요. 제품을 쓰는 사람이라면 누구나 아이디어가 있다고 생각하니까요. 그러다 보면 어느 순간 '내 전문성은 뭔가? 내 일의 근거는 뭐지?'라고 하게 돼요. 그런데 실험(experimentation) 체계를 만들면 그 순간 그 일이 과학이 되는 거예요.
text_zh: 做产品经理最头疼的就是，谁都觉得自己能干这活儿。只要是用过产品的人，都觉得自己有想法，搞得你有时候会想："我这个岗位到底专业在哪儿？我的科学方法在哪儿？"但是一旦你建立起实验机制(experimentation)，这事儿就变科学了。
text_es: El problema de ser product manager es que todo el mundo cree que puede hacer tu trabajo. Cualquiera que use el producto piensa que tiene buenas ideas, entonces llega un momento en que te preguntas: "¿Cuál es mi disciplina? ¿Cuál es mi ciencia?" En el momento que implementas experimentación, ya lo has vuelto científico.
context: Mayur discusses the fundamental challenge product managers face in establishing credibility and professional discipline. He explains how experimentation transforms product management from subjective opinion-based work into a scientific discipline, giving PMs the authority to make data-driven decisions when everyone around them has product opinions.
vocabulary_highlights: discipline, made it scientific

speaker: Mayur Kamat
speaker_expertise: Product Management, Growth Strategy, User Experience
text: Strategy is a little bit overrated for product. For most product managers, your strategy should be, "How fast can I go from hypothesis to data?"
text_ko: 제품(product) 쪽에서는 전략(strategy)이 좀 과대평가된 편이에요. 대부분의 프로덕트 매니저들(product managers)에게 필요한 전략은 "가설(hypothesis)을 얼마나 빨리 데이터(data)로 검증할 수 있느냐"예요.
text_zh: 对于产品来说，战略这个东西有点被高估了。对大部分产品经理而言，你的策略其实就是："我怎么能最快地从假设验证到拿到数据？"
text_es: Para productos, la estrategia está un poco sobrevalorada. Para la mayoría de product managers, tu estrategia debería ser: "¿Qué tan rápido puedo pasar de la hipótesis a los datos?"
context: Lenny mentions that many new people in their careers want to focus on strategy and big picture thinking. Mayur responds with a contrarian view that product strategy is overrated, arguing that instead of spending time on high-level strategic planning, product managers should focus on rapidly testing hypotheses and gathering data to inform decisions.
vocabulary_highlights: overrated for product, hypothesis to data

speaker: Mayur Kamat
speaker_expertise: Product Management, Growth Strategy, User Experience
text: The scale of Binance is pretty mind-boggling. Just to give the history, they started in 2017 as a crypto exchange, when there were other crypto exchange on the market for years, like Coinbase. Within six months, they became number one. That's unprecedented.
text_ko: 바이낸스 규모는 정말 어마어마해요. 간단히 말하면, 2017년에 암호화폐 거래소(crypto exchange)로 시작했는데, 그때 이미 코인베이스 같은 거래소들이 수년째 시장에 있었어요. 그런데 6개월 만에 업계 1위가 됐어요. 전례가 없어요.
text_zh: 币安的规模真的让人震惊。简单说说历史，他们2017年才开始做加密货币交易所，当时市面上已经有其他交易所运营好几年了，比如Coinbase。结果六个月内，他们就做到了第一名。这简直闻所未闻。
text_es: La escala de Binance es realmente impresionante. Para darte un poco de contexto, empezaron en 2017 como un exchange de cripto, cuando ya había otros exchanges de criptomonedas en el mercado desde hacía años, como Coinbase. En seis meses se convirtieron en el número uno. Eso no tiene precedentes.
context: Lenny asks Mayur about his experience working at Binance and how it was unique compared to other companies. Mayur explains the extraordinary scale and rapid growth of Binance, describing how they achieved market leadership in just six months despite established competitors, which he characterizes as an unprecedented achievement in the industry.
vocabulary_highlights: mind-boggling, unprecedented

speaker: Mayur Kamat
speaker_expertise: Product Management, Growth Strategy, User Experience
text: You cannot have one-on-ones when you have 55 direct reports, so there's a culture of one-to-many and doing that as often as possible. The leadership team, for example, met every day, and because the leadership team was spread across the world, we met at 11:00 PM when I was in Singapore every day.
text_ko: 직속 팀원(direct reports)이 55명이나 되면 원온원(one-on-ones)은 할 수가 없어서, 일대다(one-to-many) 방식으로 가능한 한 자주 그렇게 하는 문화가 있어요. 예를 들어 리더십 팀(leadership team)은 매일 모였고, 팀이 전 세계에 흩어져 있어서 제가 싱가포르에 있을 때는 매일 밤 11시에 회의를 했어요.
text_zh: 你管着55个直属下属，根本没法一对一谈话，所以我们的文化就是一对多，而且要尽可能多地这样做。比如说领导团队，我们每天都开会，因为领导团队分布在世界各地，我在新加坡的时候，我们每天晚上11点开会。
text_es: No puedes tener reuniones uno a uno cuando tienes 55 personas reportándote directamente, así que hay una cultura de uno a muchos y hacerlo lo más seguido posible. El equipo de liderazgo, por ejemplo, se reunía todos los días, y como el equipo directivo estaba repartido por todo el mundo, nos reuníamos a las 11:00 PM cuando yo estaba en Singapur, todos los días.
context: Mayur describes the unique organizational structure at Binance where the CEO had 55 direct reports and how this extreme flat structure required different management approaches. He explains how they handled communication at scale through daily leadership meetings across time zones, illustrating the intense operational pace required to manage such rapid growth.
vocabulary_highlights: one-to-many, spread across the world

speaker: Mayur Kamat
speaker_expertise: Product Management, Growth Strategy, User Experience
text: There's some people in Sydney, Australia, so it was 1:00 AM for them.
text_ko: 호주 시드니에 계신 분들이 있어서 그분들한테는 새벽 1시였어요.
text_zh: 悉尼那边有些人参加，对他们来说是凌晨一点。
text_es: Había gente de Sydney, Australia, así que para ellos era la 1:00 de la madrugada.
context: Lenny comments on the daily 11 PM leadership meetings, hoping the timing was better for other team members around the world. Mayur responds that the meeting time was actually even worse for some team members, with people in Sydney joining at 1:00 AM, demonstrating the extreme commitment and sacrifice required in Binance's high-intensity work culture.

speaker: Mayur Kamat
speaker_expertise: Product Management, Growth Strategy, User Experience
text: The best thing you can do is find companies that are growing fast because it compounds your learning at a much faster interval. Just the basic compound interest formula, even if your interest rate is low, if you're compounding daily versus compounding yearly, after two years, you will be at a whole different stage at the end point.
text_ko: 가장 좋은 건 빠르게 성장하는 회사를 찾는 거예요. 그게 배움이 훨씬 더 빠르게 누적되거든요. 기본적인 복리(compound interest) 공식처럼, 이자율(interest rate)이 낮더라도 일 단위로 복리(compounding daily)하면 연 단위로 복리(compounding yearly)할 때와 비교해 2년 뒤엔 완전히 다른 단계에 있게 돼요.
text_zh: 最好的选择就是找那些发展很快的公司，因为这样你学东西的速度会成倍增长。就像复利(compound interest)的基本公式一样，哪怕你的利率不高，但如果你是按天复利而不是按年复利，两年下来，最终的结果会完全不一样。
text_es: Lo mejor que puedes hacer es buscar empresas que estén creciendo rápido porque eso acelera tu aprendizaje de manera exponencial. Es como la fórmula básica del interés compuesto - aunque tu tasa de interés sea baja, si capitalizas diariamente en lugar de anualmente, después de dos años vas a estar en un nivel completamente distinto al final.
context: Lenny asks Mayur for career advice for product managers who want to accelerate their careers and get unstuck. Mayur emphasizes that working at fast-growing companies is the most important factor for career development, using the compound interest metaphor to explain how frequent learning opportunities at growing companies create exponential career growth compared to slower-paced environments.
vocabulary_highlights: compounds your learning, compound interest formula, compounding daily

speaker: Megan Cook
text: I think often when there's difficult conversations, or those conflicts come up, you can put them off until they become much bigger. Or if somebody is conflict adverse, they can try to avoid having it at all. But by having a specific slot of time in your week for something like that, then you're sort of in that mindset. You know you're going in there to solve a hard problem.
text_ko: 어려운 대화나 갈등이 생기면 사람들은 그걸 훨씬 더 커질 때까지 미루는 경우가 많아요. 혹은 갈등 회피적(conflict-averse)인 사람은 아예 그런 대화를 피하려고 하죠. 그런데 주중에 그런 일을 위한 특정 시간대(specific slot of time)를 따로 정해 두면, 그 시간에는 문제를 해결하러 가는 마인드셋(mindset)이 되어요. 그래서 들어갈 때부터 '어려운 문제를 풀러 간다'는 걸 알고 가게 돼요.
text_zh: 我觉得很多时候遇到那些比较难谈的事儿，或者有什么冲突矛盾，大家就容易拖着不处理，结果问题越滚越大。还有些人就是怕冲突，能躲就躲，根本不想碰这些事。但是如果你每周专门留出一个时间段来处理这类问题，那你就会提前做好心理准备，知道自己是要去解决棘手问题的，心态就不一样了。
text_es: Creo que muchas veces, cuando hay conversaciones difíciles o surgen esos conflictos, los vas posponiendo hasta que se vuelven mucho más grandes. O si alguien le huye al conflicto, puede tratar de evitarlo completamente. Pero si tienes un espacio específico en tu semana para ese tipo de cosas, entonces ya te pones en esa mentalidad. Sabes que vas a entrar ahí a resolver un problema complicado.
context: Lenny asks Megan about creating psychological safety on teams. Megan explains her team's "Fight Club" practice - a weekly 30-minute meeting between herself, her engineering leader, and design leader specifically dedicated to addressing conflicts. She argues that having a designated time for difficult conversations prevents issues from growing larger and helps conflict-averse people engage with problems they might otherwise avoid.
vocabulary_highlights: conflict adverse, specific slot of time, sort of in that mindset

speaker: Megan Cook
text: So took that decision and went, okay, we need to look at psychological safety in that team or we're never going to get to some of these bigger, bolder, more innovative ideas. And so brought my group, product managers together, and we sat around and discussed it and all together came up with some ideas that we've implemented since then, which has had a really good impact.
text_ko: 그래서 그렇게 결정하고는 “그 팀의 심리적 안전성(psychological safety)을 살펴봐야 해요. 안 그러면 더 크고 대담하고 혁신적인 아이디어로는 못 갈 거예요”라고 했어요. 그래서 제 그룹의 프로덕트 매니저들(product managers)을 한자리에 모아 편하게 이야기하고 함께 아이디어를 모아 몇 가지를 실행해봤더니 정말 좋은 효과가 있었어요.
text_zh: 所以我们就做了这个决定，觉得必须得解决团队里心理安全感(psychological safety)的问题，不然永远也搞不出那些更大胆、更有创新性的想法。然后我就把产品经理们都叫过来，大家坐一块儿讨论，一起想出了一些点子，后来都落地执行了，效果还真不错。
text_es: Entonces tomé esa decisión y dije, bueno, necesitamos revisar la seguridad psicológica (psychological safety) en ese equipo o nunca vamos a llegar a esas ideas más grandes, más audaces y más innovadoras. Así que reuní a mi grupo, a los product managers, nos sentamos a platicar sobre el tema y entre todos surgieron unas ideas que hemos implementado desde entonces, y la verdad es que han tenido muy buen impacto.
context: Lenny asks why creating play and psychological safety are important to Megan. She explains that she noticed concerning signs on her team - junior members weren't speaking up, feedback was anonymous, and work was becoming "painfully polished" before leadership review. After attending a leadership conference where she learned that the opposite of play is fear (not work), she realized her team needed better psychological safety to generate innovative ideas.
vocabulary_highlights: bigger, bolder, more innovative ideas, brought my group together, really good impact

speaker: Megan Cook
text: Most of the time when people come to me and they want to ask how to get by-in, they've got a date in mind, they've got a particular meeting and they have this idea where they're going to crop this perfect proposal, they're going to present it, everyone's going to give them thumbs up and they win. And that's the wrong attitude I think even to start with to getting buy-in. It's more of a journey.
text_ko: 대부분 저한테 와서 “어떻게 지지(buy-in)를 얻죠?” 하고 물어보시는 분들은 이미 날짜를 정해놨고, 특정 회의에서 완벽한 제안을 내놓으면 모두가 찬성해주고 끝날 거라고 생각해요. 그런데 그런 태도로 시작하는 건 애초에 지지(buy-in)를 얻는 올바른 자세가 아니에요. 지지(buy-in)를 얻는 건 한 번에 끝나는 일이 아니라 긴 여정이에요.
text_zh: 大部分时候，当有人来问我怎么获得支持的时候，他们心里都有个时间表，有个具体的会议安排，然后就想着要搞个完美的提案出来，一展示完大家就会拍手叫好，然后他们就赢了。但我觉得这种心态从一开始就是错的，想要获得别人的支持(buy-in)不是这么搞的，这更像是一个过程。
text_es: La mayoría de las veces cuando la gente viene a preguntarme cómo conseguir que les aprueben algo, ya tienen una fecha en mente, ya tienen una reunión específica y se han hecho la idea de que van a sacar esta propuesta perfecta, la van a presentar, todos les van a dar el visto bueno y listo, ganaron. Y esa mentalidad está mal desde el principio para conseguir apoyo. Es más bien un proceso largo.
context: Lenny asks Megan for advice on getting buy-in for ideas from executives, noting that this is particularly challenging at Atlassian due to having two CEOs and being fully remote. Megan explains that most people approach buy-in incorrectly by trying to present one perfect proposal in a single meeting and expecting immediate approval. Instead, she emphasizes that getting buy-in is an iterative process that requires ongoing relationship building.
vocabulary_highlights: crop this perfect proposal, give them thumbs up, more of a journey

speaker: Megan Cook
text: I think when you come to the meeting going, okay, here's the top-back so we actually know, and here's the hypotheses and here's my plan to prove or disprove them, then you're exposing your idea for people to go, oh, here's more that I know about that hypotheses, or here's some data that you don't have or here's another way to think about it.
text_ko: 회의에 들어가서 "여기 핵심 배경과 우리가 세운 가설들(hypotheses), 그리고 그 가설을 증명·반증할 제 계획입니다"라고 말하면, 제 아이디어를 드러내는 거예요. 그러면 다른 사람들이 "아, 그 가설에 대해 제가 아는 게 더 있고요", "당신이 없는 이런 데이터가 있고요", "다른 방식으로도 생각해볼 수 있어요"라고 추가로 말해줄 수 있어요.
text_zh: 我觉得当你来开会的时候，就说，好，这就是我们现在掌握的大概情况，这些是我的假设，这是我用来验证或者推翻这些假设的计划。这样一来，你就把你的想法摊开了，别人就能说，哦，关于这个假设我还知道一些别的，或者我这里有些你没有的数据，或者我们可以换个角度来看这个问题。
text_es: Creo que cuando llegas a la reunión diciendo, "mira, aquí está el contexto general (top-back) para que todos sepamos de qué estamos hablando, estas son las hipótesis y este es mi plan para confirmarlas o descartarlas", entonces estás poniendo tu idea sobre la mesa para que la gente pueda decir "ah, yo sé algo más sobre esa hipótesis" o "tengo datos que tú no tienes" o "se me ocurre otra forma de verlo".
context: Lenny asks Megan how to come across as more open-minded when seeking buy-in, since many people think they're open to feedback but really aren't. Megan suggests being explicit about distinguishing facts from hypotheses when presenting ideas. She argues this approach invites others to contribute additional knowledge and perspectives, rather than presenting everything as absolute truth.
vocabulary_highlights: exposing your idea, prove or disprove them, another way to think about it

speaker: Megan Cook
text: So we worked together to find a low cost way for those teams to help us make the changes that we need to, but they didn't have to bear the brunt of all the development costs. So each of those teams flipped forward, we call them a shepherd, so that as our developers came in and made changes in the code base that this shepherd would make sure that they weren't causing any issues and we're doing reviews and reviews of designs and things like that.
text_ko: 그래서 저희는 함께 협력해서 그 팀들이 필요한 변경을 도와줄 수 있으면서도 모든 개발 비용을 전부 떠안지 않아도 되는 저비용 방안을 찾았어요. 각 팀에서 한 명씩 앞으로 나와 역할을 맡았고, 우리는 그들을 책임자(shepherd)라고 불렀어요. 저희 개발자들이 코드베이스(code base)를 수정할 때 그 책임자가 문제가 생기지 않는지 확인해주고, 디자인 검토(design reviews) 같은 검토 작업도 계속해줬어요.
text_zh: 所以我们一起想办法，用低成本的方式让那些团队帮我们做必要的改动，但又不用让他们承担所有的开发费用。每个团队都派了一个人出来，我们叫他们"牧羊人"(shepherd)，这样当我们的开发人员进来改代码的时候，这个牧羊人就负责确保不会出什么问题，还要做代码审查、设计审查这些工作。
text_es: Entonces trabajamos juntos para encontrar una forma económica de que esos equipos nos ayudaran a hacer los cambios que necesitábamos, pero sin que tuvieran que cargar con todos los costos de desarrollo. Así que cada uno de esos equipos asignó a alguien, les decimos "pastor" (shepherd), para que cuando nuestros desarrolladores llegaran y hicieran cambios en el código, este pastor se asegurara de que no estuvieran causando problemas y estuviera haciendo revisiones de diseños y ese tipo de cosas.
context: Lenny asks about Megan's approach to "fighting the good fight" - doing important work that isn't necessarily popular. Megan shares how she led a customer satisfaction (CSAT) improvement initiative at Atlassian. When she found that improving usability required coordination across many platform teams with different goals, she created a solution where each team provided a "shepherd" to review changes rather than bearing full development costs.
vocabulary_highlights: bear the brunt of, flipped forward, shepherd

speaker: Megan Cook
text: I think if you have a hypothesis and you can start small, you can get that investment more easily, you can show success, you can always build on that in the future to get more and more. But in this case, we got about 40 people to come and join onto this. And then as we shipped things, we just made sure that it kept being quite small.
text_ko: 제 생각에는 가설(hypothesis)이 있고 작게 시작할 수 있다면 투자를 더 쉽게 받을 수 있고, 성공을 보여줄 수 있어서 그걸 바탕으로 나중에 점점 더 확장해 나갈 수 있어요. 근데 이번에는 약 40명이 이 프로젝트에 합류했고, 출시(ship)할 때도 계속 소규모로 유지하려고 했어요.
text_zh: 我觉得如果你有个假设，然后从小规模开始做起，这样更容易拿到投资，也能证明你做得成功，以后再慢慢扩大规模拿更多钱嘛。我们当时就找了大概40个人加入进来。后续在出产品的时候，我们也一直确保规模控制得比较小。
text_es: Creo que si tienes una hipótesis y puedes empezar en pequeño, es mucho más fácil conseguir esa inversión, puedes demostrar que funciona, y siempre puedes ir construyendo sobre eso para conseguir más y más adelante. Pero en este caso, logramos que unas 40 personas se sumaran al proyecto. Y después, conforme fuimos lanzando cosas, nos aseguramos de mantenerlo bastante pequeño.
context: Megan continues explaining her CSAT improvement initiative strategy. She emphasizes the importance of starting with small investments to prove hypotheses before asking for larger commitments. Her approach involved getting initial buy-in for a 40-person team while keeping individual releases small to maintain momentum and demonstrate success incrementally.
vocabulary_highlights: build on that, join onto this, kept being quite small

speaker: Megan Cook
text: Where I dropped the ball was more about what I should have realized about that feature. So automation, it's super useful. It can be used by a whole slew of people who aren't just developers. It could be used in every single product. It's more than just moving things to a new status. And so I should have realized that we could have built this amazing service that every product could have moved themselves forward with.
text_ko: 제가 실수한 건 그 기능(feature)에 대해 미리 알아차렸어야 할 부분을 놓친 거예요. 자동화(automation)는 정말 유용해서 개발자들(developers)뿐만 아니라 훨씬 많은 사람들이 쓸 수 있고, 거의 모든 제품(product)에 적용될 수 있어요. 단순히 상태(status)를 바꾸는 것 이상의 의미가 있어요. 그래서 우리가 각 제품(product)이 스스로 다음 단계로 나아가게 해주는 멋진 서비스를 만들 수 있었다는 걸 제가 알아차렸어야 했어요.
text_zh: 我当时掉链子的地方是，没有意识到那个功能的真正价值。自动化这个东西，真的特别有用，不光是开发人员能用，各种各样的人都能用上。每个产品都能用得上，不只是简单的状态更新那么回事。我当时就应该想到，我们完全可以做出一个超棒的服务，让每个产品都能借这个东西往前推进。
text_es: Donde la regué fue en no darme cuenta de lo que realmente significaba esa funcionalidad. O sea, la automatización es súper útil. La puede usar un montón de gente que no son solo desarrolladores. Se podría usar en absolutamente todos los productos. Va mucho más allá de simplemente cambiar el estatus de las cosas. Entonces me debería haber dado cuenta de que podríamos haber construido este servicio increíble con el que todos los productos se habrían podido impulsar hacia adelante.
context: Lenny asks Megan to share a failure story for his "Failure Corner" segment. Megan describes missing a major opportunity early in her career when she built automation features for Jira that helped developers automatically update work status. Years later, Atlassian had to acquire a company that built the broader automation platform she could have created, costing significantly more than developing it internally would have.
vocabulary_highlights: dropped the ball, whole slew of people, moved themselves forward

speaker: Melanie Perkins
speaker_expertise: Company Building, Marketing Strategy, Leadership Development
text: I don't really know. It was really clear in my mind that it was the future and I thought the investors were wrong, frankly. But investors also gave really helpful feedback and feedback often in the form of rejection. So they would say, "Oh, your market's not big enough." And I would say, "It's going to be huge." And I'd add a new page in my pitch deck that said how big the market I believe was.
text_ko: 잘 모르겠어요. 제게는 그게 미래라는 게 정말 분명했고, 솔직히 투자자들이 틀렸다고 생각했어요. 하지만 투자자들로부터 정말 도움이 되는 피드백도 많이 받았고, 그 피드백은 종종 거절의 형태로 왔어요. 투자자들은 "아, 시장(market)이 충분히 크지 않아요."라고 했고, 저는 "엄청 커질 거예요."라고 답했어요. 그리고 제가 생각하는 시장 규모를 보여 주는 새 페이지를 피치덱(pitch deck)에 하나 더 넣었어요.
text_zh: 我也说不清楚。反正在我心里特别确定这就是未来的趋势，老实说我觉得那些投资人都看走眼了。不过投资人也给了挺有用的反馈，虽然这些反馈经常是以拒绝的形式出现的。他们会说，"你这个市场不够大。"我就回他们，"这市场会很大的。"然后我就在我的路演(pitch deck)里加一页，专门讲我认为这个市场能有多大。
text_es: No tenía muy claro la verdad. Para mí estaba clarísimo que eso era el futuro y pensaba que los inversionistas estaban equivocados, te digo la verdad. Pero los inversionistas también me dieron retroalimentación súper útil, aunque muchas veces en forma de rechazo. Me decían cosas como "Tu mercado no es lo suficientemente grande" y yo les contestaba "Va a ser enorme." Y entonces agregaba una página nueva a mi presentación explicando qué tan grande creía yo que iba a ser el mercado.
context: Lenny asks Melanie about how it felt to be rejected by over 100 investors early on, especially given that Canva is now a $40+ billion company. Melanie explains that despite the constant rejections, she remained convinced that her vision represented the future of design. She describes how she used investor feedback constructively - when investors said her market wasn't big enough or that she was the same as competitors, she would add new slides to her pitch deck addressing these concerns and demonstrating the market opportunity and competitive differentiation.
vocabulary_highlights: feedback often in the form of rejection, frankly

speaker: Melanie Perkins
speaker_expertise: Company Building, Marketing Strategy, Leadership Development
text: So we have this concept of chaos to clarity and every idea starts in the chaos side, and then you have to work all the way to the other side, which is clarity. That very first step at the far end of chaos was quite an embarrassing step actually, because you don't have mastery at that point. You don't have all the answers.
text_ko: 우리는 '혼돈에서 명확성으로(chaos to clarity)'라는 개념이 있어요. 모든 아이디어는 혼돈 쪽에서 시작해서 반대편인 명확성까지 쭉 작업을 해나가야 해요. 혼돈의 가장 끝자락에서 뗀 그 첫걸음은 사실 꽤 민망해요. 그때는 마스터리(mastery)가 없고, 모든 답을 가지고 있지 않거든요.
text_zh: 我们有个"从混乱到清晰"的概念，每个想法一开始都是混乱的，然后你得一路摸索到另一头，也就是清晰的状态。其实在混乱那端迈出第一步是很尴尬的，因为那时候你还没掌握要领，也没有现成的答案。
text_es: Entonces tenemos este concepto de caos a claridad, y cada idea empieza del lado del caos, y después tienes que trabajar hasta llegar al otro extremo, que es la claridad. Ese primer paso allá en el extremo del caos fue bastante incómodo la verdad, porque en ese momento no dominas el tema. No tienes todas las respuestas.
context: Lenny asks Melanie about how she operationalizes her Column B thinking approach, specifically mentioning that Canva creates vision decks for every project. Melanie explains Canva's "chaos to clarity" framework - every new idea begins in chaos (just a vague concept in your head) and must progress through incremental steps toward clarity (becoming more concrete and visible to others). She acknowledges that the initial step feels embarrassing because you don't have expertise yet, but emphasizes the importance of taking that first step anyway.
vocabulary_highlights: chaos to clarity, far end of chaos, quite an embarrassing step, mastery at that point

speaker: Melanie Perkins
speaker_expertise: Company Building, Marketing Strategy, Leadership Development
text: The thing that I love about a crazy big goal is that you feel completely inadequate before it. You want to work really hard to will it into existence. I really like to start by just imagining what is the future that you actually want Right now? I have a wall in my house in my office, which is my vision for what I'd like the world to look like in 2050.
text_ko: 엄청 크게 잡은 목표의 좋은 점은 그 목표 앞에서는 스스로가 완전히 부족하다고 느낀다는 거예요. 그래서 그걸 현실로 만들기 위해 정말 열심히 일하게 돼요. 저는 보통 지금 당장 내가 진짜로 원하는 미래가 어떤 건지 상상하는 것부터 시작하는 걸 정말 좋아해요. 집에 있는 제 작업실 벽 한쪽에는 2050년쯤 세상이 어떤 모습이길 바라는지에 대한 제 비전(vision)을 붙여놨어요.
text_zh: 我特别喜欢那种疯狂大目标的地方就是，面对它你会觉得自己完全不够格。这会让你特别想拼命去把它变成现实。我很喜欢从想象开始——你到底想要什么样的未来？现在我家办公室的墙上贴着我对2050年世界的愿景图。
text_es: Lo que me encanta de una meta súper ambiciosa es que te sientes completamente incapaz frente a ella. Te dan ganas de trabajar durísimo para hacerla realidad. Me gusta mucho empezar simplemente imaginando cuál es el futuro que realmente quieres. Ahora mismo tengo una pared en mi oficina en casa que es mi visión de cómo me gustaría que se viera el mundo en 2050.
context: Lenny asks about Canva's value of "Crazy Big Goals" and why having such ambitious goals is so important. Melanie explains that crazy big goals are powerful because they make you feel inadequate, which motivates you to work extremely hard to achieve them. She emphasizes starting by imagining the ideal future you want to create, and mentions that she has a physical vision wall in her office showing what she wants the world to look like by 2050.
vocabulary_highlights: feel completely inadequate, will it into existence

speaker: Melanie Perkins
speaker_expertise: Company Building, Marketing Strategy, Leadership Development
text: I think it's sort of the dark tunnel analogy. Or chaos to clarity, let's go with that one. It's a slightly friendlier analogy and I think just taking the rejection and turning into things that you can control. So I can control my pitch deck, I can control the number of people I'm speaking to and I just spoke to literally everyone.
text_ko: 저는 이걸 일종의 '어두운 터널' 비유(dark tunnel analogy) 같다고 생각해요. 아니면 '혼돈에서 명료함으로(chaos to clarity)'—그걸로 할게요. 그게 좀 더 친근한 비유고, 거절을 받아들이고 그걸 내가 통제할 수 있는 것들로 바꾸는 거예요. 예를 들어 피치덱(pitch deck)은 제가 관리할 수 있고, 제가 만나는 사람 수도 제가 조절할 수 있어요. 그래서 저는 말 그대로 모든 사람에게 다 이야기했어요.
text_zh: 我觉得这就像是从混乱到清晰的过程，用这个比喻更友好一些。关键是要把被拒绝这件事转化成你能掌控的东西。比如说，我可以控制我的路演材料(pitch deck)，我可以控制接触多少人，所以我就是见人就聊，逢人就讲。
text_es: Creo que es como la analogía del túnel oscuro. O mejor dicho, del caos a la claridad, vamos con esa que suena más amigable. Se trata de tomar el rechazo y convertirlo en cosas que sí puedes controlar. O sea, yo puedo controlar mi pitch deck, puedo controlar con cuántas personas hablo, y literalmente hablé con todo el mundo.
context: Lenny asks Melanie for advice for founders who are struggling with fundraising, given her experience of being rejected by over 100 investors. Melanie suggests using her "chaos to clarity" framework and focusing on what you can control when facing rejection. Rather than taking rejections personally, she recommends channeling that feedback into improving controllable elements like your pitch deck and expanding the number of investors you talk to.
vocabulary_highlights: dark tunnel analogy, slightly friendlier analogy, turning into things that you can control, literally everyone

speaker: Melanie Perkins
speaker_expertise: Company Building, Marketing Strategy, Leadership Development
text: I think it was kind of everything internally. We made it into a bit of a game. We had this game board and I bought these little rubber ducky sort of bath toys and we had, so we all the little components represented as a bath toy on this board and there was all these stages of went launched in product. There was an emergency lane at the end of it was home and hosed.
text_ko: 사실 내부적으로는 전부 다 그런 식이었던 것 같아요. 우리는 이걸 약간 게임처럼 만들었어요. 게임판(game board)을 하나 만들어서 제가 작은 고무오리(rubber ducky) 같은 목욕 장난감들을 몇 개 샀고, 제품의 작은 구성 요소들을 그 장난감으로 게임판 위에 표시해 놨죠. 제품 출시(product launch)의 여러 단계가 다 보이게 해두고, 마지막에는 비상 레인(emergency lane)이 있어서 거기까지 가면 '끝났다, 해결됐다' 같은 상태가 되는 식이었어요.
text_zh: 我觉得内部什么招都用上了。我们把它搞成了一个小游戏的形式。我们做了个游戏板，我还买了那种小橡皮鸭子洗澡玩具，然后把所有的小模块都用这些小鸭子在板子上代表，产品发布有好多个阶段。最后还设了个紧急通道，走到头就算大功告成了。
text_es: Creo que fue un poco de todo internamente. Lo convertimos en una especie de juego. Teníamos este tablero de juego y compré estos patitos de goma, como juguetes de baño, y teníamos todos los componentes representados como juguetes de baño en este tablero. Había todas estas etapas por las que pasaba el producto cuando se lanzaba. Había un carril de emergencia y al final estaba la meta donde ya teníamos todo listo y controlado.
context: Lenny asks about the internal mood during Canva's two-year period when they had to rewrite their entire codebase and couldn't ship any new product features. Melanie describes how the team dealt with this challenging time by gamifying the process. They created a board game with rubber duck toys representing different components, with various stages leading to product launch, including an "emergency lane" that ended at "home and hosed" (Australian slang meaning safe or completed).
vocabulary_highlights: made it into a bit of a game, rubber ducky sort of bath toys, home and hosed

speaker: Melanie Perkins
speaker_expertise: Company Building, Marketing Strategy, Leadership Development
text: We are giving away 1.5 billion of product a year now. And so the impact that that can have and the ripple effect of that I think is pretty great. And I think for all of us, it gives a lot more meaning to our work than, "Get Rich."
text_ko: 지금은 연간 15억 규모의 제품을 무료로 나눠주고 있어요. 그래서 그로 인한 영향과 파급 효과(ripple effect)가 꽤 크다고 생각해요. 그리고 우리 모두에게 그건 단순히 '부자 되기'(Get Rich)보다 훨씬 더 큰 의미를 줘요.
text_zh: 我们现在每年免费提供15亿美元的产品。这个影响力和连锁反应我觉得挺厉害的。对我们所有人来说，这比单纯"发财致富"给工作带来了更多意义。
text_es: Ahora estamos regalando productos por valor de 1.5 mil millones al año. Y el impacto que eso puede tener, con todo el efecto dominó que genera, me parece increíble. Y creo que para todos nosotros, eso le da mucho más sentido a nuestro trabajo que simplemente "hacerse rico."
context: Lenny notes that many companies have philanthropic initiatives that aren't central to their operations, but observes that Canva's two-step plan (build a valuable company, then do good) seems core to how the company operates. Melanie explains the scope of Canva's giving, including their education product used by 100 million people monthly and their nonprofit program.
