She emphasizes that giving away $1.5 billion worth of product annually creates meaningful ripple effects and provides the team with deeper purpose beyond just financial success.
vocabulary_highlights: ripple effect of that, lot more meaning to our work, Get Rich

speaker: Melissa Perri
text: Do you want to hire 10,000 product managers and let them all do these things off the side of their desk and then concentrate on strategic work 30% of the time or do you want them concentrating on strategic work majority of the time and then help build a product operations team around them that can create these shared systems and this infrastructure to allow them to work better?
text_ko: 프로덕트 매니저(product managers) 1만 명을 뽑아서 이런 일들을 각자 책상 옆에서 겸사겸사 처리하게 두고 전략 업무에는 30%만 집중하게 할 건가요, 아니면 전략 업무에 대부분의 시간을 쓰게 하고 그들 주변에 프로덕트 오퍼레이션(product operations) 팀을 만들어 공통 시스템과 인프라를 구축해 더 효율적으로 일하게 도와줄 건가요?
text_zh: 你是想招一万个产品经理，让他们把这些事情当副业来做，然后只有30%的时间搞战略工作？还是说让他们把大部分时间都专注在战略上，然后帮他们搭建一个产品运营(product operations)团队，建立这些共享系统和基础设施，让他们能更高效地工作？
text_es: ¿Quieres contratar 10,000 gerentes de producto y dejar que hagan todas estas cosas como tareas secundarias mientras se concentran en trabajo estratégico solo el 30% del tiempo, o prefieres que se enfoquen en trabajo estratégico la mayor parte del tiempo y ayudar a construir un equipo de operaciones de producto a su alrededor que pueda crear estos sistemas compartidos y esta infraestructura para que trabajen mejor?
context: Lenny asks Melissa about the value proposition of product operations. Melissa is explaining the fundamental choice companies face when scaling their product management function. She's arguing that as companies grow, product managers end up spending most of their time on operational tasks like data analysis, research coordination, and process management rather than strategic work. The alternative is to build a product operations team that can handle these operational tasks through shared systems and infrastructure, allowing product managers to focus primarily on strategic decisions.
vocabulary_highlights: off the side of their desk, shared systems, infrastructure
topics: Product Management, Leadership & Management, Strategy & Planning

speaker: Melissa Perri
text: Product operations does not take away decision making rights from the product manager. It's there to inform them. So if you're judging your success as a product manager of, "Hey, I do the SQL queries and I have to spend the 50 hours to set up all these customer interviews and calls," that to me is very operational process type work, but it's not work that's going to help you make a decision about your product.
text_ko: 제품 운영(Product operations)은 프로덕트 매니저(product manager)의 의사결정 권한을 빼앗는 게 아니에요. 결정을 내리도록 정보를 제공하는 역할이에요. 그래서 본인이 '내가 SQL 쿼리(SQL queries)를 직접 돌리고, 고객 인터뷰랑 통화 일정을 잡느라 50시간을 써야 성공한 매니저다'라고 스스로 평가한다면, 그건 제게는 굉장히 운영적이고 프로세스 중심적인 업무예요. 그런데 그런 일들은 제품에 대한 결정을 내리는 데 실제로 도움이 되지 않아요.
text_zh: 产品运营(product operations)并不是要抢产品经理的决策权，而是为了给他们提供信息支持。如果你作为产品经理，把成功标准定义为"我得自己写SQL查询，还得花50个小时去安排客户访谈和电话沟通"，那在我看来，这些确实是很重要的运营流程工作，但这些事情并不能真正帮你做出关于产品的决策。
text_es: Las operaciones de producto no le quitan al product manager el derecho a tomar decisiones. Están ahí para darle información. Entonces, si como product manager estás midiendo tu éxito por "Oye, yo hago las consultas SQL y tengo que dedicar 50 horas a organizar todas estas entrevistas y llamadas con clientes," para mí eso es trabajo muy operativo, pero no es trabajo que te va a ayudar a tomar decisiones sobre tu producto.
context: Lenny expresses concern that product managers might feel threatened by product operations taking over their responsibilities. Melissa is addressing the fear that product ops will diminish the PM role by clarifying that product ops handles operational tasks, not strategic decision-making. She argues that activities like writing SQL queries and coordinating interviews are time-consuming operational work that doesn't directly contribute to product decisions, and product ops should handle these tasks to free up PMs for more strategic work.
vocabulary_highlights: judging your success, operational process type work

speaker: Melissa Perri
text: What I constantly hear from product managers though is, "I am so busy, I don't have time to do the things that I need to do correctly. I'm so busy trying to line up customer interviews," or, "I'm so busy just trying to get data out of systems. I'm fighting these fights to get the things that I need to do my job correctly that I don't have time to do my job correctly," and that's what we're trying to help them with.
text_ko: 제가 프로덕트 매니저(product managers)들한테서 늘 듣는 말이 있어요. "너무 바빠서 제대로 해야 할 일을 할 시간이 없어요. 고객 인터뷰(customer interviews) 일정 잡느라 정신이 없고," 또는 "시스템에서 데이터(data)를 뽑아오느라 바빠서, 일하려면 필요한 것들을 얻기 위해 계속 싸우느라 정작 일을 제대로 할 시간이 없어요." 그래서 우리가 도와주려는 게 바로 그 부분이에요.
text_zh: 不过我经常听产品经理们说，"我忙得要死，根本没时间把该做的事情做到位。我光是安排客户访谈就忙得团团转"，或者"我光是从系统里搞数据就够呛了。我天天为了拿到做好工作需要的东西跟各种人扯皮，结果反而没时间好好干活"，这就是我们想帮他们解决的问题。
text_es: Lo que escucho constantemente de los product managers es: "Estoy súper ocupado, no tengo tiempo para hacer las cosas como se debe. Ando corriendo tratando de conseguir entrevistas con clientes" o "Estoy batallando para sacar datos de los sistemas. Me la paso peleando para conseguir lo que necesito para hacer bien mi trabajo, que al final no tengo tiempo para hacerlo bien", y justo en eso es donde les queremos echar la mano.
context: Melissa continues explaining why product operations is valuable for product managers. She's describing the common frustration PMs experience when they get bogged down in operational tasks like scheduling interviews and extracting data from systems. The core problem she identifies is that PMs spend so much time on these supporting activities that they can't focus on their primary job responsibilities of making strategic product decisions and working directly on product development.
vocabulary_highlights: line up customer interviews, fighting these fights, get data out of systems

speaker: Melissa Perri
text: We usually see that high growth companies start with business data and insights and make sure that they can actually monitor what they're doing and get the strategic inputs. We see larger companies and enterprises go more towards the process and governance, especially if they're in, let's say, a transformation because they don't have the infrastructure to run good product.
text_ko: 보통 고성장 기업들(high growth companies)은 비즈니스 데이터와 인사이트(business data and insights)에서 출발해서, 자신들이 하는 일을 실제로 모니터링할 수 있는지와 전략적 인풋(strategic inputs)을 제대로 확보하고 있는지를 확인해요. 반면에 더 큰 기업들이나 엔터프라이즈(enterprises)는 프로세스와 거버넌스(process and governance)에 더 초점을 맞추는 편인데, 특히 트랜스포메이션(transformation) 중이라면 좋은 프로덕트(product)를 운영할 인프라(infrastructure)가 갖춰져 있지 않아서 그렇게 하는 경우가 많아요.
text_zh: 我们通常看到高增长的公司都是从业务数据和洞察入手，确保他们能实时监控自己在做什么，获得战略层面的输入。而那些大企业更倾向于先搞流程和治理这一套，特别是在转型期的时候，因为他们缺乏运营好产品的基础设施。
text_es: Por lo general vemos que las empresas de alto crecimiento arrancan con los datos del negocio y los insights, y se aseguran de que realmente puedan monitorear lo que están haciendo y obtener esa información estratégica clave. En cambio, las empresas más grandes y las corporaciones tienden más hacia los procesos y la gobernanza, sobre todo si están en una transformación, digamos, porque no tienen la infraestructura para manejar bien el producto.
context: Lenny asks about which of the three product ops pillars (business data and insights, customer and market insights, or process and practices) is most important. Melissa explains that the priority depends on the company's stage and situation. High-growth companies typically need better data and insights to make strategic decisions quickly, while larger, more established companies often need help with processes and governance, especially during digital transformations when they're building their product management capabilities from scratch.
vocabulary_highlights: strategic inputs, run good product
topics: Product Management, Strategy & Planning, Leadership & Management

speaker: Melissa Perri
text: I also think it's funny how many people want to be a product manager until they realize what product management entails. This happens a lot and I saw it with my MBA students at Harvard too. We do a whole class, they play a product manager. I had a lot of people opt out of being a product manager at the end of it. They were like, "I did not realize it was like that. I did not realize I had to do so many things."
text_ko: 저도 많은 사람이 프로덕트 매니저(product manager)가 되고 싶어하지만, 정작 프로덕트 매니지먼트(product management)가 뭔지를 알게 되면 생각이 바뀌는 게 참 신기해요. 하버드에서 가르친 제 MBA 학생들에게도 똑같이 그걸 봤어요. 수업 하나를 통째로 구성해서 학생들이 프로덕트 매니저 역할을 맡아보게 했는데, 수업이 끝날 때쯤 꽤 많은 학생이 "이런 줄 몰랐어요. 이렇게 해야 할 일이 많은 줄 몰랐어요"라며 프로덕트 매니저 하기를 포기하겠다고 하더라고요.
text_zh: 我也觉得挺有意思的，很多人都想当产品经理(product manager)，但真正了解产品管理(product management)是干什么的时候就不想干了。这种情况特别常见，我在哈佛教MBA学生的时候也经常遇到。我们专门有一堂课让他们体验当产品经理，结果课程结束后好多人都打退堂鼓了。他们就说："我之前完全不知道是这样的，没想到要管这么多事儿。"
text_es: También me parece gracioso cómo hay muchísima gente que quiere ser product manager hasta que se da cuenta de lo que realmente implica la gestión de producto. Pasa un montón y lo vi también con mis estudiantes de MBA en Harvard. Hacemos toda una clase donde interpretan el papel de product manager. Al final, muchos decidían que no era lo suyo. Me decían, "No tenía ni idea de que fuera así. No sabía que había que hacer tantas cosas."
context: Melissa is discussing why people underestimate the complexity of product management roles. She shares her experience teaching MBA students at Harvard, where students initially express interest in product management but change their minds after experiencing what the role actually involves. This supports her argument for product operations - that PM roles have become overwhelmingly complex with too many different responsibilities, making it difficult for people to excel at the strategic aspects of the job.
vocabulary_highlights: opt out, I did not realize it was like that

speaker: Melissa Perri
text: So I work with all these CPOs, these VPs of product and they're like ... I see them just not working on strategy. I'm like, "Why are you not working on strategy?" and they're like, "I don't have time to do that. I'm in here stopping all these fires. I'm figuring out what template I should put my roadmap in." Like I said, it's not hard. They know what template it should be in, but think about if you now can delegate that to somebody else and say, "I want it in this template. Go roll it out. Go roll it out, go train everybody on it, find the right software for it, do it."
text_ko: 저는 많은 CPO(Chief Product Officer)와 VP(부사장)들과 일하는데, 그분들이 전략에 집중하지 않는 걸 자주 봐요. 그래서 "왜 전략에 신경 안 쓰세요?"라고 물어보면, "그럴 시간이 없어요. 여기서 불 끄느라 바빠요. 로드맵에 어떤 템플릿을 써야 할지 고민하고 있어요."라고 하더라고요. 사실 그렇게 어렵지 않은데, 그분들도 어떤 템플릿을 써야 하는지 알고 있어요. 그런데 만약 그걸 다른 사람에게 맡길 수 있다면, "이 템플릿으로 해주세요. 진행해 주세요. 모든 사람에게 교육도 시켜 주세요, 적절한 소프트웨어도 찾아 주세요, 진행해 주세요."라고 할 수 있다면 좋겠죠.
text_zh: 我跟这些CPO、产品VP们打交道，发现他们就是不做战略规划。我就问他们，"你们怎么不做战略啊？"他们说，"哪有时间啊，天天在这儿救火呢。还得琢磨路线图(roadmap)用什么模板。"其实吧，这事儿不难，他们心里清楚该用什么模板，但是你想想，如果现在能把这活儿交给别人，直接说，"我要用这个模板，你去搞定。去推广，去培训大家怎么用，找合适的软件，全给我办了。"
text_es: Entonces trabajo con todos estos CPOs, estos VPs de producto y están como... los veo que simplemente no se enfocan en estrategia. Les digo, "¿Por qué no están trabajando en estrategia?" y me dicen, "No tengo tiempo para eso. Estoy aquí apagando fuegos todo el día. Estoy tratando de decidir en qué plantilla poner mi roadmap." Como dije, no es difícil. Ellos saben en qué plantilla debería ir, pero piensen si ahora pueden delegar eso a alguien más y decir, "Lo quiero en esta plantilla. Ve e impleméntalo. Ve e impleméntalo, ve y entrena a todos, busca el software adecuado, hazlo."
context: Melissa is explaining how product operations benefits not just individual product managers but also senior product leaders. She describes how Chief Product Officers and VPs of Product get consumed by operational tasks like creating templates and stopping fires rather than focusing on strategic work. Her point is that while these leaders know what needs to be done operationally, having someone else execute and roll out these operational tasks frees up the leaders to focus on the high-level strategic work that justifies their senior roles and salaries.
vocabulary_highlights: stopping all these fires, go roll it out, delegate that to somebody else

speaker: Melissa Perri
text: Scaled Agile Framework came out of the desire to figure out how do we scale Scrum and different processes. I do not recommend using SAFe. Every single person I have talked to who likes SAFe, found success with SAFe, they ended up ripping it up and making it into something else.
text_ko: 스케일드 애자일 프레임워크(Scaled Agile Framework, SAFe)는 우리가 스크럼(Scrum)과 여러 프로세스를 어떻게 확장할지 알아내고자 하는 욕구에서 나온 거예요. 다만 저는 SAFe 사용을 권하지 않아요. 제가 만나서 얘기해본 사람들 중 SAFe를 좋아하거나 SAFe로 성공했다고 말한 분들은 전부 결국 그 프레임워크를 다 뜯어고쳐서 자기들만의 방식으로 바꿔버리더라고요.
text_zh: 规模化敏捷框架(Scaled Agile Framework)当初就是想解决一个问题：怎么把Scrum这些流程放大到更大规模。但我真的不建议用SAFe。我接触过的每一个说SAFe好用、用SAFe成功了的人，到最后都把它拆得七零八落，改成了别的东西。
text_es: El Scaled Agile Framework (SAFe) surgió de la necesidad de descifrar cómo escalar Scrum y otros procesos. Pero te digo que no recomiendo usar SAFe. Cada persona con la que he hablado que le gustó SAFe, que tuvo éxito con SAFe, al final terminó deshaciéndose de todo eso y convirtiéndolo en algo completamente diferente.
context: Lenny asks Melissa about SAFe (Scaled Agile Framework), which is a methodology for implementing agile practices at large organizations. SAFe is a structured approach that provides detailed frameworks and processes for coordinating multiple development teams. Melissa explains her strong opposition to using SAFe as prescribed, noting that even organizations that claim success with it ultimately modify it so extensively that it no longer resembles the original framework.
vocabulary_highlights: ripping it up, ended up

speaker: Melissa Perri
text: A lot of large companies turn to Scrum or to the frameworks, and it's because they traditionally didn't grow up building software. When you look at agile methodologies, what we're really saying there is we want to be able to move quickly and deliver great value to customers. If you embrace those principles, you're going to do well.
text_ko: 많은 대기업이 스크럼(Scrum)이나 여러 프레임워크들(frameworks)에 의지하는 건, 전통적으로 소프트웨어를 직접 만들어온 조직이 아니었기 때문이에요. 애자일 방법론(agile methodologies)을 보면 핵심은 빠르게 움직여 고객에게 큰 가치를 제공하자는 거예요. 그 원칙들을 받아들이면 잘 해낼 거예요.
text_zh: 很多大公司都开始用Scrum或者各种框架(framework)，主要是因为他们以前不是做软件出身的。你看敏捷开发方法(agile methodologies)，说白了就是我们希望能快速行动，给客户带来真正的价值。如果你能抓住这些核心理念，肯定能做得不错。
text_es: Muchas empresas grandes recurren a Scrum o a estos frameworks, y es porque tradicionalmente no crecieron desarrollando software. Cuando ves las metodologías ágiles, lo que realmente estamos diciendo ahí es que queremos poder movernos rápido y entregar gran valor a los clientes. Si abrazas esos principios, te va a ir bien.
context: Lenny asks why some companies need these frameworks while others (like Silicon Valley startups) seem to build great products without them. Melissa explains that large, traditional companies (banks, telecoms, etc.) turn to structured frameworks because they lack experience building software natively. She emphasizes that the core agile principles of speed and customer value are sound, but rigid adherence to processes can be counterproductive.
vocabulary_highlights: didn't grow up building, turn to, embrace those principles
topics: Product Management, Strategy & Planning, Leadership & Management

speaker: Melissa Perri
text: This product owner role did not emerge from product management as we know it today. It was a way to help the developers prioritize what to work on. I ended up going to a ton of agile conferences and speaking about product management, and I started to learn that there was this product owner role in Scrum.
text_ko: 이 프로덕트 오너 역할(product owner role)은 지금 우리가 아는 프로덕트 매니지먼트(product management)에서 바로 나온 건 아니었어요. 원래는 개발자들이 무엇을 먼저 작업할지 우선순위를 정하도록 돕기 위한 방식이었죠. 결국 저는 수많은 애자일 컨퍼런스(agile conferences)에 가서 프로덕트 매니지먼트(product management)에 대해 발표를 했고, 그 과정에서 스크럼(Scrum) 안에 이런 프로덕트 오너 역할(product owner role)이 있다는 걸 알게 됐어요.
text_zh: 这个产品负责人(product owner)的角色其实不是从我们现在理解的产品管理里发展出来的。当时就是为了帮开发人员搞清楚优先级，知道先做什么后做什么。后来我跑了好多敏捷开发(agile)的会议，去讲产品管理的事儿，慢慢才发现原来Scrum里面有这么个产品负责人的角色。
text_es: Este rol de product owner no surgió del product management como lo conocemos hoy. Era una forma de ayudar a los desarrolladores a priorizar en qué trabajar. Terminé yendo a un montón de conferencias ágiles hablando sobre gestión de productos, y ahí fue cuando empecé a enterarme de que existía este rol de product owner en Scrum.
context: Lenny mentions his surprise at seeing product owner as one of the fastest-growing roles in tech, despite never encountering it in his circles. Melissa explains the origins of the product owner role, clarifying that it emerged from Scrum methodology to help developers with prioritization, not from traditional product management practices. She discovered this disconnect when speaking at agile conferences where she learned about this parallel evolution of product roles.
vocabulary_highlights: emerge from, ended up going to a ton of, started to learn

speaker: Melissa Perri
text: What I found was that there was a really big misconception about what those people should be doing compared to what they teach in agile and Scrum versus what we all consider great product management. I've been trying to fill that gap for the last almost 10 years working with these companies here.
text_ko: 제가 발견한 건, 애자일(agile)과 스크럼(Scrum)에서 가르치는 것과 우리가 생각하는 훌륭한 제품 관리 사이에, 그 역할을 맡은 분들이 실제로 해야 할 일에 대해 큰 오해가 있다는 점이에요. 지난 거의 10년 동안 여기서 여러 회사들과 일하면서 그 간극을 메우려고 노력해왔어요.
text_zh: 我发现有个很大的误区，就是关于这些人应该做什么，敏捷(agile)和Scrum里教的那套，跟我们认为的优秀产品管理(product management)之间，差距挺大的。过去快10年，我一直在跟这些公司合作，想要填补这个空白。
text_es: Lo que me di cuenta es que había una confusión bastante grande sobre lo que esa gente debería estar haciendo comparado con lo que enseñan en agile y Scrum versus lo que todos consideramos una buena gestión de producto. He estado tratando de cerrar esa brecha durante casi 10 años trabajando con estas empresas aquí.
context: Melissa describes her experience training product owners at large companies during agile transformations around 2014-2015. She discovered that people from various backgrounds (developers, business analysts, project managers) were suddenly designated as product owners without proper training in actual product management principles. This created a significant gap between what these newly-minted product owners were doing versus what constitutes effective product management.
vocabulary_highlights: really big misconception, fill that gap
topics: Product Management, Coaching & Development, Career Development

speaker: Melissa Perri
text: When I've worked with companies on digital transformations, you want a development operating model. That's where a lot of these agile methodologies came out of. You have to understand that's just the development operating model, that's not actually going to help you with go-to-market, with launching your products and with product management.
text_ko: 디지털 전환을 진행하는 기업들과 일해보면 개발 운영 모델(development operating model)이 필요하다고 느끼게 돼요. 많은 애자일 방법론(agile methodologies)도 바로 거기서 나온 거고요. 다만 그건 어디까지나 개발 운영 모델일 뿐이라 시장 진입(go-to-market), 제품 출시나 제품 관리(product management)에는 직접적인 도움이 되지는 않아요.
text_zh: 我跟一些公司合作做数字化转型的时候，你得有一个开发运营模式。很多敏捷方法论(agile methodologies)就是从这儿来的。但你要明白，这只是开发运营模式，对你的市场推广(go-to-market)、产品发布，还有产品管理其实帮不上什么忙。
text_es: Cuando he trabajado con empresas en transformaciones digitales, necesitas un modelo operativo de desarrollo. De ahí es donde salieron muchas de estas metodologías ágiles. Tienes que entender que eso es solo el modelo operativo de desarrollo, eso en realidad no te va a ayudar con el go-to-market, con lanzar tus productos ni con la gestión de productos.
context: Lenny asks for advice on how leaders should approach digital transformation instead of adopting SAFe. Melissa explains that agile methodologies only address the development operating model - how teams build software - but don't solve the broader challenges of product strategy, go-to-market execution, and comprehensive product management. She emphasizes that organizations need to think beyond just development processes.
vocabulary_highlights: development operating model, came out of, go-to-market
topics: Product Management, Strategy & Planning, Leadership & Management

speaker: Melissa Perri
text: I'd say there's a lot of things you can do to help move your companies forward, and I have seen in a lot of these organizations too, a groundswell of product owners and product managers saying, 'Hey, what's next for me? What's going on?' That makes the organizations go and figure it out.
text_ko: 제가 보기엔 회사를 앞으로 나아가게 하려면 할 수 있는 일이 정말 많아요. 그리고 많은 조직에서 프로덕트 오너(product owners)랑 프로덕트 매니저(product managers)들이 '다음엔 내가 뭘 하지? 지금 무슨 일이 벌어지고 있는 거지?'라고 묻기 시작하는 큰 흐름이 생기는 것도 많이 봤어요. 그런 분위기가 조직을 움직여서 스스로 답을 찾아내게 만들어요.
text_zh: 我觉得有很多事情可以帮助推动公司向前发展，而且我在很多组织里都看到，产品负责人(product owners)和产品经理(product managers)开始主动问："嘿，我下一步该怎么走？接下来会发生什么？"正是这种声音让组织开始思考并找出解决方案。
text_es: Yo diría que hay muchas cosas que puedes hacer para impulsar a tus empresas hacia adelante, y también he visto en muchas de estas organizaciones un movimiento desde abajo donde los product owners y product managers están diciendo: "Oye, ¿qué sigue para mí? ¿Qué está pasando?" Y eso hace que las organizaciones se pongan las pilas y lo resuelvan.
context: Lenny asks what advice Melissa has for product owners who want to advance their careers and become more strategic. Melissa encourages people to speak up about career development and push for more strategic responsibilities. She explains that when multiple employees raise these concerns, it creates organizational pressure that forces leadership to address career pathing and role clarity issues.
vocabulary_highlights: move your companies forward, groundswell, go and figure it out

speaker: Melissa Perri
text: When I think of product operating models and what I do with companies is we break out how do you determine product strategy? Do you have a good product strategy? You look at your organizational design. How are we actually organized around our products? Do we have good coverage of product managers and do we have skilled product managers up and down the organization?
text_ko: 제가 프로덕트 운영 모델(product operating models)을 생각하고 회사들과 일할 때는, 제품 전략(product strategy)을 어떻게 정하는지부터 세부적으로 나눠서 봐요. 좋은 제품 전략이 있는지, 조직 설계(organizational design)는 어떤지 살펴보고요. 실제로 제품을 중심으로 어떻게 조직되어 있는지, 프로덕트 매니저(product managers)가 충분히 배치돼 있는지, 조직 전반에 걸쳐 능력 있는 프로덕트 매니저들이 있는지도 확인해요.
text_zh: 说到产品运营模式(product operating models)，我跟公司合作的时候会拆解几个问题：你们怎么制定产品策略的？产品策略做得好不好？还要看组织架构设计，就是围绕产品我们的组织架构搭得怎么样？产品经理的覆盖面够不够，从上到下各个层级的产品经理水平行不行？
text_es: Cuando pienso en modelos operativos de producto y lo que hago con las empresas es que desglosamos: ¿cómo determinas tu estrategia de producto? ¿Tienes una buena estrategia de producto? Miras el diseño organizacional. ¿Cómo estamos realmente organizados alrededor de nuestros productos? ¿Tenemos buena cobertura de product managers y tenemos product managers capacitados en toda la organización?
context: Continuing her advice on digital transformation, Melissa outlines her framework for building effective product operating models. Instead of just focusing on development processes like SAFe does, she emphasizes the need to examine product strategy, organizational structure, and ensuring proper coverage of skilled product managers throughout the organization. This represents a more holistic approach to transformation than just implementing agile frameworks.
vocabulary_highlights: break out, good coverage, up and down the organization
topics: Product Management, Strategy & Planning, Leadership & Management

speaker: Melissa Perri
text: I've met a lot of organizations that think most of their issues are in the training of their people. And 99% of the time I see that it's actually in the way that they're setting their goals and deploying their strategy. Because once you train those people, they have no context on what to work towards.
text_ko: 사람들에 대한 교육(training)에 문제가 있다고 생각하는 조직을 많이 만났어요. 그런데 제 경험상 99%는 실제 문제의 원인이 목표 설정(goals)과 전략 실행(strategy deployment)에 있어요. 사람들을 교육해도 그들이 무엇을 위해 일해야 하는지에 대한 맥락(context)이 없으면 소용이 없거든요.
text_zh: 我接触过很多公司，他们都觉得问题主要出在员工培训上。但我发现99%的情况下，真正的问题其实是他们设定目标和执行策略的方式有问题。因为你把人培训完了，他们根本不知道该朝哪个方向努力。
text_es: He conocido muchas organizaciones que creen que la mayoría de sus problemas están en la capacitación de su gente. Y el 99% de las veces me doy cuenta de que en realidad está en cómo están planteando sus objetivos y ejecutando su estrategia. Porque una vez que capacitas a esa gente, no tienen ni idea hacia dónde enfocar sus esfuerzos.
context: Lenny asks Melissa about common problems she encounters when helping companies improve their product organizations. Melissa explains that most organizations mistakenly believe their problems stem from inadequate training of their product teams. However, she observes that the real issue is usually strategic - companies fail to set clear goals and deploy coherent strategies, leaving even well-trained employees without proper direction.
vocabulary_highlights: deploying their strategy, no context on what to work towards

speaker: Melissa Perri
text: So it's such a holistic approach when you actually go through these transformations, or try to set up a product organization, so you either need somebody in there to do it, or you've got to really be ready to move when somebody comes in to help you.
text_ko: 실제로 이런 변화(transformation)를 겪거나 프로덕트 조직(product organization)을 구성하려고 할 땐 전체적인 접근(holistic approach)이 필요해요. 그래서 그걸 직접 해줄 내부 인력이 있든가, 외부에서 도우러 왔을 때 바로 움직일 준비가 돼 있어야 해요.
text_zh: 所以当你真正要做这些转型，或者想要搭建产品组织的时候，这其实是一个很全面的方法，要么你得有人在内部来做这个事儿，要么你得做好准备，等有人来帮你的时候能够马上行动起来。
text_es: Entonces es un enfoque realmente integral cuando pasas por estas transformaciones, o cuando tratas de montar una organización de producto, así que o necesitas a alguien interno que lo haga, or tienes que estar listo para moverte cuando llegue alguien de afuera para echarte la mano.
context: Melissa continues explaining why product transformations are challenging. She emphasizes that building an effective product organization requires a comprehensive approach that addresses multiple interconnected elements - not just training people, but also establishing proper goal-setting and strategy deployment. Companies need either internal leadership capable of driving this transformation or external help, but they must be prepared to take decisive action.
vocabulary_highlights: holistic approach, really be ready to move

speaker: Melissa Perri
text: At that point, they have to rethink their entire strategy. And then they have to focus because they have all of these choices to keep building for their existing customers and just take everything off the backlog because everybody's requesting things, they really have to focus and prioritize.
text_ko: 그때가 되면 전체 전략을 다시 생각해야 해요. 선택지가 너무 많아서 기존 고객을 위해 계속 개발해 나갈지, 모두가 요청하는 걸 다 백로그(backlog)에서 꺼내 처리할지 결정하려면 정말 집중해서 우선순위를 정해야 해요.
text_zh: 到了那个时候，他们就得重新想整个战略了。然后必须得聚焦，因为他们有太多选择了——既要为现有客户继续开发功能，又要处理积压需求(backlog)里的一堆需求，大家都在提各种要求，所以真的必须得重点突出，分清轻重缓急。
text_es: En ese momento, tienen que replantearse toda su estrategia. Y después tienen que enfocarse porque tienen un montón de opciones para seguir desarrollando cosas para sus clientes actuales y sacar todo del backlog porque todos están pidiendo cosas, realmente tienen que enfocarse y priorizar.
context: Lenny asks about common problems at modern tech companies that Melissa encounters in her consulting work. Melissa describes the critical junction point when SaaS companies transition from finding product-market fit to scaling up. At this stage, companies face the challenge of managing a complex portfolio while having numerous feature requests from existing customers, making strategic focus and prioritization essential for success.
vocabulary_highlights: take everything off the backlog

speaker: Melissa Perri
text: A big sign for me, when I've come into organizations to help CEOs where they're like, do we need a product person to oversee this? I don't know what a product person does. And I usually talk them through like, hey, what are the challenges you're having? And they tell me everything, and I'm like, okay, these ones are actually caused by you not having that partner to work with.
text_ko: 제가 CEO들을 도와 조직에 들어갈 때마다 한 가지 확실한 신호가 있어요. "이걸 감독할 프로덕트 담당자(product person)가 필요할까? 그 사람이 뭘 하는지도 잘 모르겠네"라고 말할 때요. 저는 보통 "지금 어떤 문제들이 있으세요?" 하고 물어보고, 그들이 겪는 걸 다 얘기하게 해요. 그러면 "아, 이 문제들 중 상당수는 사실 그 역할을 같이해 줄 파트너가 없어서 생긴 거예요"라고 말하곤 해요.
text_zh: 我进入一些公司帮助CEO的时候，经常会遇到一个很明显的信号，就是他们会问我，我们是不是需要找个产品人员来负责这块？说实话我也不太清楚产品人员具体是干什么的。这时候我通常会跟他们聊，问他们现在遇到什么挑战？他们会跟我说一大堆问题，然后我就会告诉他们，其实你们说的这些问题，很多都是因为你们缺少一个能配合你们工作的合作伙伴造成的。
text_es: Una señal muy clara para mí, cuando llego a organizaciones para ayudar a CEOs que me dicen, ¿necesitamos a alguien de producto para supervisar esto? No sé qué hace una persona de producto. Y normalmente los voy guiando con preguntas como, oye, ¿cuáles son los retos que están enfrentando? Me cuentan todo, y yo les digo, okay, estos problemas en realidad se deben a que no tienen ese socio estratégico (partner) con quien trabajar.
context: Lenny asks when it's time for a company to hire a Chief Product Officer (CPO). Melissa explains that a key indicator is when CEOs and executives feel disconnected from their product and technology teams. When leadership doesn't understand what's happening in product development or whether goals are being achieved, it signals the need for a senior product leader who can serve as a strategic partner to the CEO and communicate effectively with the board and executive team.
vocabulary_highlights: partner to work with

speaker: Melissa Perri
text: And I would try to ladder that up myself into a strategy and see if it was connected. And if it wasn't connected, that's telling me somebody's not formulating the strategy and deploying it down. And then, that's telling me there is a lack of strategy at the top.
text_ko: 저는 그걸 제가 직접 상위 전략으로 연결해(ladder up) 보고 실제로 연결돼 있는지 확인해요. 만약 연결돼 있지 않다면, 그건 누군가 전략을 제대로 수립해서 하향 전개(deploy down)하지 않았다는 신호예요. 결국 최고위층에 전략이 부족하다는 뜻이에요.
text_zh: 然后我会试着把这些往上串联成一个完整的战略，看看它们之间有没有关联。如果发现没什么关联的话，那就说明上面的人没有制定好战略，也没有往下传达执行。这就告诉我，高层缺乏战略思维。
text_es: Y yo trataría de conectar eso hacia arriba con la estrategia para ver si había coherencia. Y si no estaba conectado, eso me dice que alguien no está formulando bien la estrategia ni bajándola a los equipos. Y entonces ahí me doy cuenta de que falta estrategia clara desde arriba.
context: Melissa describes her diagnostic process when consulting with companies. She asks individual teams what they're working on and why, then attempts to connect their work to an overarching strategy. When she can't make these connections, it indicates that either no comprehensive strategy exists at the executive level, or the strategy isn't being effectively communicated and deployed throughout the organization.
vocabulary_highlights: ladder that up, deploying it down

speaker: Melissa Perri
text: But if we think about all the things that teams do in isolation, it's not enough, usually, to move those business metrics. So what people do in a lack of strategy is they spread the team too thin across tons of initiatives. One team usually isn't enough to get some really hard hitting metrics out there.
text_ko: 하지만 팀이 각자 따로따로 일하는 것만으로는 보통 비즈니스 지표(business metrics)를 충분히 움직이기 어려워요. 그래서 전략이 없으면 사람들은 팀을 너무 얇게 쪼개 여러 이니셔티브(initiatives)에 투입해요. 한 팀만으로는 보통 큰 임팩트를 주는 핵심 지표(core metrics)를 개선하기에 부족해요.
text_zh: 但是你想想，如果团队各自为政、单打独斗的话，通常是很难推动那些关键业务指标的。所以很多人在缺乏策略的情况下，就会让团队在一大堆项目上摊得太开，精力分散。光靠一个团队，通常是很难做出那种真正有冲击力的数据表现的。
text_es: Pero si pensamos en todas las cosas que los equipos hacen por separado, normalmente no es suficiente para mover esas métricas del negocio. Entonces lo que pasa cuando no hay una estrategia clara es que dispersan al equipo en demasiadas iniciativas a la vez. Un solo equipo generalmente no basta para conseguir métricas realmente contundentes.
context: Melissa explains what happens when companies lack proper strategy deployment. She describes how individual teams might be working on various features and enhancements, but when these efforts aren't coordinated toward common strategic goals, they fail to create meaningful business impact. Without strategic focus, organizations tend to scatter their resources across too many initiatives, preventing any single effort from achieving significant results.
vocabulary_highlights: spread the team too thin, hard hitting metrics

speaker: Melissa Perri
text: And the best teams I've ever seen, the most successful companies I've ever seen, everybody works together, and they're like, these are our goals, and these are our business goals. So when strategy is deployed correctly and you have that type of culture, too, with your executives, they're all on the same page.
text_ko: 제가 본 최고의 팀들과 가장 성공한 회사들은 다 같이 협업해요. 모두가 '이게 우리의 목표고, 이게 비즈니스 목표(business goals)예요'라고 공감해요. 그래서 전략(strategy)이 제대로 실행되고 경영진(executives)에게도 그런 문화가 자리 잡으면, 모두가 같은 방향을 보고 있어요.
text_zh: 我见过的最好的团队，最成功的那些公司，大家都是拧成一股绳，就像，这是咱们的目标，这是咱们的业务目标。所以当战略部署到位，再加上高管层都有这种文化氛围，大家想法都特别一致。
text_es: Y los mejores equipos que he visto, las empresas más exitosas que conozco, todos trabajan en conjunto, y están como que "estos son nuestros objetivos, estas son nuestras metas del negocio." Entonces cuando la estrategia se ejecuta bien y tienes ese tipo de cultura también, con tus ejecutivos, todos están en la misma sintonía.
context: Lenny asks about signs that indicate a company has good strategy in place. Melissa describes what effective strategy deployment looks like - when executives function as a unified team with aligned goals rather than competing against each other. She contrasts this with dysfunctional organizations where different departments have conflicting priorities, explaining that successful companies achieve cross-functional alignment around shared business objectives.
vocabulary_highlights: they're all on the same page

speaker: Melissa Tan
text: My aha moment of the value of first principles thinking was when I was at Dropbox. We would hire a ton of really smart people that had never done sales and had them do sales. There are a lot of disadvantages to that, but I do think it led to a ton of innovation. That's how we got our very innovative go-to market motions because a lot of those people then moved into different functions at the company. They had all this context on who the user was. They had talked to so many different users at that point. If you take people that are just super smart, they've never done it before, one advantage of that is they can innovate because I think they come in with, I don't know anything. Let me just figure this out.
text_ko: 제가 Dropbox에 있을 때 근본 원리 사고(first principles thinking)의 가치가 확 확 느껴졌어요. 우리는 영업을 해본 적 없는 정말 똑똑한 사람들을 대거 뽑아 영업을 시키곤 했어요. 단점이 많긴 했지만, 그 과정이 엄청난 혁신을 불러왔다고 생각해요. 그렇게 해서 아주 창의적인 시장 진출 방식(go-to-market motions)이 나오게 됐죠. 많은 사람들이 회사에서 다른 역할로 이동하면서 사용자에 대한 맥락을 다 갖게 되었고, 그때까지 정말 다양한 사용자와 많이 이야기했거든요. 단지 엄청 똑똑한데 경험은 없는 사람들을 데려오면 한 가지 큰 장점이 있어요. 스스로 ‘아무것도 모른다. 그냥 해보면서 알아내자’라는 마음으로 들어오니까 혁신을 만들어낼 수 있더라고요.
text_zh: 我在Dropbox的时候突然想明白了第一性原理思维(first principles thinking)的价值。我们当时会招一堆特别聪明但完全没做过销售的人来做销售。这样做确实有不少弊端，但我觉得也带来了很多创新。我们那些很有创新性的市场策略(go-to market motions)就是这么来的，因为很多这样的人后来转到了公司其他部门。他们对用户是谁有很深的了解，跟各种各样的用户都聊过。如果你找那些特别聪明但从来没做过这件事的人，好处就是他们能创新，因为他们会想"我什么都不懂，那就自己琢磨琢磨吧"。
text_es: Mi momento de revelación sobre el valor del pensamiento desde principios básicos (first principles thinking) fue cuando estaba en Dropbox. Contratábamos un montón de gente súper inteligente que nunca había hecho ventas y los poníamos a vender. Eso tiene muchas desventajas, pero creo que nos llevó a innovar muchísimo. Así fue como desarrollamos estrategias de salida al mercado (go-to-market) súper innovadoras, porque muchas de esas personas después se movieron a diferentes áreas de la empresa. Tenían todo ese contexto de quién era el usuario. Habían hablado con tantos usuarios diferentes para ese momento. Si tomas gente que es súper inteligente pero que nunca lo ha hecho antes, una ventaja es que pueden innovar porque llegan con esa mentalidad de "no sé nada de esto, déjame descifrar cómo funciona."
context: Lenny asks Melissa for an example of first principles thinking in action. Melissa explains how Dropbox unconventionally hired very smart people with no sales experience to do sales roles. While this approach had disadvantages, it created unexpected innovation in their go-to-market strategies because these newcomers approached problems without preconceived notions about 'how things should be done.'
vocabulary_highlights: aha moment, go-to market motions, ton of innovation

speaker: Melissa Tan
text: I think the things that Dropbox got right, one of them was definitely hiring. So when I think about 2013, Dropbox was actually known in the tech circles as a place that was very selective, very difficult to get into. You could have an amazing resume, and Dropbox was really selective about the type of people they brought in. So I think they looked for two main things. They looked for first principles thinkers, so not necessarily your experience, but how do you approach problems, how do you know the right questions to ask? And then create your own framework around that.
text_ko: 제 생각에 드롭박스가 잘한 것 중 하나는 채용이에요. 2013년을 떠올리면, 드롭박스는 기술 업계에서 매우 선별적이고 들어가기 힘든 곳으로 알려져 있었어요. 이력서가 아무리 훌륭해도 드롭박스는 어떤 사람을 뽑을지에 대해 굉장히 까다롭게 골랐어요. 제가 보기엔 그들이 주로 본 건 두 가지였어요. 첫째는 근본 원리에서 출발해 생각하는 사람들 (first-principles thinkers)이에요. 즉, 단순히 경력 자체가 중요한 게 아니라 문제에 어떻게 접근하는지, 어떤 질문을 던져야 할지를 아는지 — 그리고 그걸 바탕으로 자신만의 프레임워크 (framework)를 만드는지였어요.
text_zh: 我觉得Dropbox做得特别对的一件事，就是他们的招人策略。你想想2013年那会儿，Dropbox在科技圈里是出了名的挑，特别难进。哪怕你简历再漂亮，他们对人的要求也是相当严格的。我觉得他们主要看两个方面：一个是要会从根本上思考问题的人，也就是说不光看你的工作经验，更看你怎么解决问题，知不知道该问什么关键问题；然后在这基础上，能不能建立起自己的一套思路和方法。
text_es: Creo que una de las cosas que Dropbox hizo súper bien fue el tema de contratación. Si me pongo a pensar en el 2013, Dropbox ya tenía fama en los círculos tech de ser un lugar súper selectivo, súper difícil de entrar. Podías tener un currículum impresionante, y aun así Dropbox era muy exigente con el tipo de gente que traían al equipo. Entonces creo que buscaban dos cosas principales. Primero, buscaban gente que pensara desde primeros principios (first principles thinkers), o sea, no necesariamente tu experiencia, sino cómo abordas los problemas, cómo sabes hacer las preguntas correctas. Y después que pudieras crear tu propio marco de trabajo alrededor de eso.
context: Lenny asks Melissa about what Dropbox did right during their growth phase from 2013-2017. Melissa explains that Dropbox's hiring philosophy focused on two key traits rather than just experience: first principles thinking (the ability to approach problems from scratch and ask the right questions) and being collaborative team players. This selective hiring approach, despite candidates having strong resumes, helped drive innovation throughout the company.
vocabulary_highlights: tech circles, first principles thinkers, create your own framework

speaker: Melissa Tan
text: I don't think that they're mutually exclusive of each other because I think the other thing that I really emphasize on my team is being very results oriented. So as a growth leader, for better or for worse, everything you do is very measurable. And so I actually think this is why a lot of folks on my team, something that they actually appreciate is knowing what success looks like and knowing how they'll be measured. And I actually create a very results-oriented culture on the team where it's clear what our goals are, we break it down into the individual levers, it's clear how success is measured for each individual.
text_ko: 이 둘이 서로 배타적이라고는 생각하지 않아요. 제 팀에서 특히 강조하는 건 매우 결과 지향적(results-oriented)이라는 점이에요. 그리고 그로스 리더(growth leader)로서, 좋든 나쁘든 하는 모든 일은 측정 가능(measurable)해요. 그래서 제 팀원들이 실제로 좋아하는 것 중 하나는 성공이 어떤 모습인지와 어떻게 평가되는지를 분명히 아는 거예요. 저는 목표가 분명한 결과 지향(results-oriented) 문화를 팀에 만들고, 목표를 개별 레버(levers)로 세분화해서 각 개인의 성공이 어떻게 측정되는지 명확히 해요.
text_zh: 我觉得这两个东西并不冲突，因为我在团队里特别强调的另一点就是要以结果为导向。作为一个增长负责人，不管怎么说，你做的每件事都是可以量化的。所以我觉得这就是为什么我团队里很多人其实很appreciate一点——他们知道成功长什么样，也知道会用什么标准来衡量他们。我确实在团队里营造了一种非常以结果为导向的文化，大家都清楚我们的目标是什么，我们会把目标拆解成各个具体的抓手，每个人的成功标准也都很明确。
text_es: No creo que sean cosas que se excluyan mutuamente porque algo que realmente enfatizo mucho con mi equipo es estar muy enfocados en los resultados. Como líder de crecimiento, para bien o para mal, todo lo que haces se puede medir muy claramente. Y por eso creo que muchas personas de mi equipo realmente valoran saber cómo se ve el éxito y entender cómo van a ser evaluados. En realidad creo una cultura muy orientada a resultados en el equipo donde está súper claro cuáles son nuestros objetivos, los desglosamos en las palancas individuales (individual levers), y queda claro cómo se mide el éxito de cada persona.
context: Lenny asks whether deeply caring about people and driving business impact are competing priorities for leaders. Melissa argues they can coexist by being very results-oriented while still caring about team members. She explains that in growth roles, everything is measurable, so she creates clarity around goals and success metrics while also supporting people's career development and giving them feedback.
vocabulary_highlights: mutually exclusive, for better or for worse, break it down into the individual levers, results-oriented

speaker: Melissa Tan
text: I think in that conversation what's important is also saying, 'I believe you can do all these things and I'm doing this to support you.' Or, 'I'm sharing this feedback because I believe in you.' Also saying that I'm here as support, as you are building that out, let me know what I can do to support you. We can jam on it together if it's helpful. Basically, I guess boil it down to one, restating your intention and why you are having that conversation to sharing that you are there to support them and offering your own help as well.
text_ko: 그 대화에서 중요한 건 “당신이 이걸 다 해낼 수 있다고 믿고, 저는 그걸 돕기 위해 이 얘기를 하는 거예요”라고 말하는 거예요. 또는 “제가 피드백을 드리는 건 당신을 믿기 때문이에요”라고도요. 그리고 “이걸 만들어 가는 동안 제가 지원할게요. 어떻게 도와드리면 좋을지 알려 주세요. 필요하면 같이 고민해볼게요”라고 덧붙이는 게 중요해요. 한마디로 정리하면, 대화를 하는 의도와 이유를 다시 확인해주고 당신을 지지한다는 걸 전하며 구체적으로 도움을 제안하는 거예요.
text_zh: 我觉得在这种对话中，重要的是要说："我相信你能做好这些事情，我这样做是为了支持你。"或者说："我给你这些反馈是因为我相信你的能力。"还要告诉他们，在你推进这些事情的时候，我会在这里支持你，有什么需要帮忙的尽管说。如果有用的话，我们可以一起头脑风暴(jam)一下。基本上，我觉得可以归结为两点：第一，重申你的初衷和为什么要进行这次对话；第二，表达你会支持他们，并主动提供帮助。
text_es: Creo que en esa conversación lo importante es también decir: "Yo sé que puedes hacer todas estas cosas y estoy haciendo esto para apoyarte." O "Te estoy dando este feedback porque creo en ti." También decirle que estás ahí para apoyarlo, que mientras va desarrollando esto, que te diga en qué lo puedes ayudar. Podemos trabajar juntos en esto si te sirve. Básicamente, creo que se resume en dos cosas: uno, reafirmar tu intención y por qué estás teniendo esa conversación, y dos, mostrar que estás ahí para apoyarlo y ofrecer tu ayuda también.
context: Lenny asks Melissa what specifically made her direct feedback feel caring rather than just critical. Melissa had earlier shared an example of giving tough feedback to a team member about moving faster. She explains that the key elements are stating your belief in the person, clarifying your supportive intentions, and actively offering to help them succeed rather than just pointing out problems.
vocabulary_highlights: jam on it together, boil it down to, restating your intention

speaker: Melissa Tan
text: I think it first starts with defining the scope that everyone is going to own and drive. So as you are setting up the team, it's important that each person on the team has scope that they can run independently and that they are excited to own and drive. So one example here is as I was leaving Dropbox, the finance team looked at our metrics and saw that each growth PM was bringing over a million in AR per year just from all the experiments.
text_ko: 저는 먼저 팀원들이 각자 책임지고 주도할 '범위(scope)'를 정의하는 것에서 시작한다고 생각해요. 그래서 팀을 꾸릴 때는 팀원 각자가 독립적으로 운영할 수 있고 스스로 맡아 추진하는 데 신나는 범위를 주는 게 중요해요. 예를 들어 제가 Dropbox를 떠날 무렵 재무팀이 지표를 보니까, 각 그로스 PM(growth PM)이 실험들(experiments)만으로 연간 AR(annual revenue) 100만 달러 이상을 가져다주고 있었어요.
text_zh: 我觉得首先得把每个人要负责和推进的范围定清楚。所以在搭团队的时候，很重要的一点是团队里每个人都要有自己能独立运作的块，而且是他们愿意去承担和推进的。举个例子，我离开Dropbox的时候，财务团队看了看我们的数据，发现每个增长PM(growth PM)光是通过各种实验，一年就能带来超过一百万的AR收入。
text_es: Creo que lo primero es definir bien qué va a manejar cada quien y de qué se va a hacer cargo. Entonces cuando estás armando el equipo, es clave que cada persona tenga su área que pueda manejar de forma independiente y que realmente le emocione liderar. Te doy un ejemplo: cuando me iba de Dropbox, el equipo de finanzas revisó nuestras métricas y vio que cada PM de crecimiento estaba generando más de un millón en ingresos anuales nada más con todos los experimentos que hacían.
context: Lenny asks Melissa how she creates a sense of ownership among team members. Melissa explains that ownership starts with giving each person meaningful scope they can run independently. She shares an example where Dropbox's finance team discovered each growth product manager was generating over $1 million in annual revenue through their experiments, demonstrating the power of giving people substantial ownership of important business outcomes.
vocabulary_highlights: scope that they can run independently, bringing over a million in AR

speaker: Melissa Tan
text: One of the most common pitfalls I'd say is not having, and I've alluded to this, not having a sense of the big picture from the start and not being strategic about what your go-to market strategy is going to be. Also, what is your pricing and packaging going to look like? So I wrote actually an article for the YC blog a few years ago with Abby about this because I felt like even at Dropbox, I mean it's a great thing. We were haphazardly finding amazing things. We had a freemium consumer product. Then we realized people wanted a Teams product, so we built a Teams product, but we never created that whole blueprint of what should it look like and what are the different connection points across consumer business.
text_ko: 제가 보기에 가장 흔한 함정 중 하나는, 앞서도 말했지만, 처음부터 큰 그림을 갖고 있지 않거나 시장 진입 전략(go-to-market strategy)을 전략적으로 세우지 않는 거예요. 또 가격 책정과 패키징(pricing and packaging)은 어떻게 할지도 고민해야 하고요. 그래서 몇 년 전에 Abby와 함께 YC 블로그에 이 주제로 글을 쓴 적이 있어요. 드롭박스도 비슷하다고 느꼈거든요. 물론 그 자체는 좋은 일이었지만 우리는 계획 없이 우연히 멋진 것들을 찾아내는 식으로 일했어요. 프리미엄(freemium) 기반의 소비자용 제품(consumer product)을 갖고 있다가 사람들이 팀용 제품(Teams product)을 원한다는 걸 알게 돼서 팀용 제품도 만들었죠. 그런데 그게 어떻게 보여야 하는지, 소비자 사업 전반에 걸친 다양한 연결 지점(connection points)은 무엇인지에 대한 전체 설계도(blueprint)는 만들지 않았어요.
text_zh: 我觉得最常见的一个坑就是，从一开始就没有大局观，对自己的市场策略(go-to market strategy)不够有规划。还有就是定价和产品包装(packaging)到底要怎么搞，也没想清楚。所以几年前我和Abby专门在YC的博客上写了篇文章聊这个事儿，因为我觉得就连Dropbox当时也是这样。当然这也不是坏事啦，我们就是这么摸着石头过河，偶然发现了一些很棒的东西。我们先做了免费增值(freemium)的个人产品，后来发现大家需要团队版，我们就又做了团队产品，但我们从来没有做过整体规划，没想过到底应该是什么样子，个人用户和企业用户之间应该怎么打通。
text_es: Una de las trampas más comunes, diría yo, es no tener, y ya he mencionado esto, no tener una visión del panorama general desde el principio y no ser estratégico con tu estrategia de salida al mercado (go-to market strategy). También, ¿cómo va a verse tu modelo de precios y empaquetado? De hecho, escribí un artículo para el blog de YC hace unos años con Abby sobre esto porque sentí que incluso en Dropbox, o sea, está genial. Estábamos encontrando cosas increíbles medio al azar. Teníamos un producto freemium para consumidores. Luego nos dimos cuenta de que la gente quería un producto para equipos, así que construimos un producto para equipos, pero nunca creamos ese blueprint completo de cómo debería verse y cuáles son los diferentes puntos de conexión entre el negocio consumer y business.
context: Lenny asks Melissa about the most common mistakes companies make when starting to invest in growth. Melissa explains that many companies lack strategic thinking about their overall go-to-market approach and pricing from the beginning. She uses Dropbox as an example - while they successfully built both consumer and business products, they never created a clear blueprint for how these should connect and work together as a cohesive strategy.
vocabulary_highlights: haphazardly finding amazing things, whole blueprint, connection points

speaker: Meltem Kuran Berkowitz
text: So I would say early days, it's very important to just go back to the basics, build the skeleton before you put on the makeup. So the first question I would ask is, do you have a website? Is it fast? Do the search engine knows that it exists? Okay, great. The next step would be, can people find it? If they can't find it, you need to write content to make sure that people can find it.
text_ko: 초기에는 기본으로 돌아가서 화장하기 전에 뼈대를 먼저 세우는 게 정말 중요해요. 그래서 제가 가장 먼저 묻는 건 웹사이트(website)가 있나요? 로딩 속도는 빠른가요? 검색 엔진(search engine)이 그 사이트의 존재를 알고 있나요? 좋아요. 다음 단계는 사람들이 그 사이트를 찾을 수 있느냐는 거예요. 못 찾는다면 사람들이 찾을 수 있도록 콘텐츠(content)를 만들어야 해요.
text_zh: 所以我觉得刚开始的时候，最重要的就是回到基本功，先把骨架搭好再化妆。我第一个要问的问题就是，你有网站吗？网站快不快？搜索引擎知道你这个网站存在吗？好，这些都有了。下一步就是，别人能不能找到你的网站？如果找不到，你就得写内容，确保别人能搜到你。
text_es: Entonces yo diría que al principio, es súper importante volver a lo básico, construir la estructura antes de ponerle los adornos. La primera pregunta que yo haría es: ¿tienes un sitio web? ¿Carga rápido? ¿Los motores de búsqueda saben que existe? Perfecto. El siguiente paso sería: ¿la gente lo puede encontrar? Si no lo pueden encontrar, necesitas crear contenido para asegurarte de que sí lo encuentren.
context: Lenny asks Meltem about how she decided where to prioritize resources and what to focus on in the early days at Deel when there were many possible growth strategies to pursue. Meltem explains her philosophy of starting with the fundamentals before moving to more advanced tactics. She emphasizes building a strong foundation with basic website functionality and discoverability before investing in paid advertising or other expensive growth channels.
vocabulary_highlights: build the skeleton before you put on the makeup, go back to the basics

speaker: Meltem Kuran Berkowitz
text: I'm not a huge fan of early awareness campaigns for B2B businesses specifically. So if you are a consumer goods founder, you can skip this part. But the reason I don't like awareness early on is because to do a proper awareness campaign, it takes time. You need to have teams that are doing the strategy, doing the creative work, and they don't always hit.
text_ko: 개인적으로 기업 대상 비즈니스(B2B)의 초기 인지도 캠페인(early awareness campaigns)은 별로 좋아하지 않아요. 소비재 창업자(consumer goods founder)라면 이 부분은 건너뛰셔도 돼요. 제가 초기 인지도를 좋아하지 않는 이유는, 제대로 된 인지도 캠페인(proper awareness campaign)을 하려면 시간이 많이 걸리기 때문이에요. 전략(strategy)을 세우는 팀과 크리에이티브 작업(creative work)을 하는 팀이 있어야 하고, 그런데 그 팀들이 항상 성과를 내는 건 아니거든요.
text_zh: 我不太赞成B2B企业早期就搞品牌认知活动。如果你是做消费品的创始人，这部分你可以跳过。我不看好早期做认知活动的原因是，要做好一个认知活动真的很费时间。你得有团队来做策略，做创意，而且还不一定能成功。
text_es: No soy muy partidario de las campañas de awareness temprano para empresas B2B específicamente. Así que si eres fundador de productos de consumo, te puedes saltar esta parte. Pero la razón por la que no me gusta el awareness al principio es porque hacer una campaña de awareness como Dios manda lleva tiempo. Necesitas equipos que estén haciendo la estrategia, haciendo el trabajo creativo, y no siempre dan en el clavo.
context: Lenny asks about Meltem's perspective on awareness campaigns and brand building versus direct response marketing. Meltem explains why she advises against investing in awareness campaigns too early for B2B businesses. Her reasoning is that awareness campaigns require significant time and resources to execute properly, and they don't always succeed, which can waste valuable time that early-stage companies can't afford.
vocabulary_highlights: they don't always hit

speaker: Meltem Kuran Berkowitz
text: The biggest mistake people make is SEO is one of those things that, you can try and automate it, you can do a lot of things that save you time, but it never stops being time-consuming. And to do it well, it is going to be time-consuming. So oftentimes people just get over it or they think it's below them to be going over and doing keyword research and doing all of those things one by one.
text_ko: 사람들이 가장 많이 하는 실수는 검색엔진최적화(SEO)를 완전히 자동화할 수 있다고 생각하는 거예요. 자동화로 시간을 절약할 수 있는 부분은 있지만, 본질적으로 계속 시간이 드는 일이에요. 잘하려면 시간이 많이 들어가요. 그래서 많은 사람이 그냥 대충 넘기거나 키워드 리서치(keyword research) 같은 걸 하나하나 직접 해보는 건 자신에게 어울리지 않는 일이라고 생각해요.
text_zh: 大家在SEO这件事上最大的误区就是，你可以尝试自动化，可以用各种方法来节省时间，但它永远都是很费时间的。而且要想做好，就是得花时间。所以很多人要么就放弃了，要么就觉得去做关键词研究(keyword research)这些一个一个来的活儿有失身份。
text_es: El error más grande que comete la gente es pensar que el SEO es algo que puedes automatizar, que hay muchas formas de ahorrarte tiempo, pero nunca deja de ser algo que te consume tiempo. Y para hacerlo bien, te va a quitar tiempo sí o sí. Entonces muchas veces la gente se harta o piensan que es algo por debajo de ellos ponerse a hacer investigación de palabras clave (keyword research) y todas esas cosas una por una.
context: Lenny asks Meltem if there's anything else important for making SEO work effectively. Meltem shares what she considers the biggest mistake people make with SEO - trying to cut corners or thinking the detailed work is beneath them. She emphasizes that successful SEO requires consistent, detailed effort including thorough keyword research, and that senior people often mistakenly think this granular work is below their level.
vocabulary_highlights: get over it, think it's below them

speaker: Meltem Kuran Berkowitz
text: Early on one of the first questions I would ask people is, what are the KPIs that you're willing to commit to? So if someone's only willing to commit to lead numbers, that's not good enough. They need to be able to commit to closed one revenue KPRs to really show that they care about the business's bottom line.
text_ko: 초반에 제가 사람들에게 제일 먼저 묻는 질문 중 하나는, 어떤 KPI(핵심성과지표)에 기꺼이 약속할 수 있느냐예요. 리드 수치(lead numbers)만 약속하려 한다면 그건 충분하지 않아요. 사업의 수익성(bottom line)에 진짜로 관심이 있다는 걸 보여주려면, 클로즈드-원 매출 KPI(closed-won revenue KPIs)까지 약속할 수 있어야 해요.
text_zh: 早期的时候，我问人的第一个问题就是，你愿意对哪些KPI负责？如果有人只愿意对线索数量(lead numbers)负责，那肯定不够。他们必须能对成交收入的KPI负责，这样才能真正证明他们在乎公司的盈利。
text_es: Al principio, una de las primeras preguntas que les hacía a las personas era: ¿a qué KPIs estás dispuesto a comprometerte? Entonces, si alguien solo está dispuesto a comprometerse con números de leads (prospectos), eso no es suficiente. Tienen que poder comprometerse con KPIs de ingresos cerrados para realmente demostrar que les importa la rentabilidad del negocio.
context: Lenny asks about what skills were most important when building the early growth team at Deel. Meltem explains her approach to hiring, focusing on finding people who are willing to be accountable for business outcomes rather than just surface-level metrics. She looks for candidates who will commit to revenue goals rather than just lead generation, as this demonstrates they understand and care about the company's ultimate success.
vocabulary_highlights: bottom line

speaker: Meltem Kuran Berkowitz
text: And at Deel we have this concept called 'little hands'. I think it's loosely translated from French, someone can correct me on that. But it basically means that no matter who you are, where you sit within the organization, you need to be willing to get into the little things and do the nitty-gritty work and not shy away from it.
text_ko: Deel에서는 '리틀 핸즈(little hands)'라는 개념이 있어요. 아마 프랑스어에서 대충 번역된 표현인 것 같은데, 정확한 분 있으면 정정해 주세요. 간단히 말하면 누구든지 조직에서 어떤 위치에 있든지 사소한 것까지 직접 챙기고 자잘하고 궂은일도 기꺼이 해내며 회피하지 않아야 한다는 뜻이에요.
text_zh: 在Deel我们有个概念叫"little hands"，我觉得这个应该是从法语翻译过来的，如果我理解错了大家可以纠正我。但基本意思就是说，不管你是谁，不管你在公司里处于什么位置，你都得愿意去处理那些琐碎的小事，愿意去干那些具体的活儿，不能嫌麻烦就躲着不做。
text_es: Y aquí en Deel tenemos este concepto que llamamos 'little hands' (manitas). Creo que viene del francés más o menos traducido, si alguien me quiere corregir, perfecto. Pero básicamente significa que no importa quién seas o en qué nivel estés dentro de la organización, tienes que estar dispuesto a meterte en los detalles pequeños y hacer el trabajo más básico, el día a día, sin hacerte el remilgoso.
context: Lenny asks about team building and what skills to look for in early hires. Meltem explains Deel's culture concept of 'little hands,' which refers to everyone being willing to do detailed, hands-on work regardless of their seniority level. She emphasizes this is crucial for early-stage companies where resources are limited and everyone needs to be willing to handle both strategic and tactical work without considering any task beneath them.
vocabulary_highlights: little hands, nitty-gritty work, shy away from

speaker: Meltem Kuran Berkowitz
text: So 'Deel speed' is very, very important for us. And that's something we expect from our team members who are committing to it. To say, what's the quickest way I can solve this problem properly? And to repeatedly push themselves to act with urgency. We also care that we remain positive. We have default optimism because we are in a new space, so if someone's going to come into Deel and they're going to be pessimistic and they're like, 'I don't think that's going to work for X, Y, Z reasons,' they're going to just slow things down.
text_ko: ‘Deel 속도(Deel speed)’는 우리한테 정말, 정말 중요해요. 그리고 그건 그에 헌신하는 팀원들에게 기대하는 거예요. ‘이 문제를 제대로, 가장 빠르게 해결하려면 어떻게 해야 하지?’라고 스스로 묻고, 계속해서 긴박감을 가지고 행동하려고 스스로를 밀어붙이는 태도요. 또 긍정적인 태도를 유지하는 것도 중요하게 생각해요. 우리가 새로운 분야에 있기 때문에 기본적으로 낙관적이에요. 누군가가 Deel에 와서 비관적으로 ‘이건 X, Y, Z 때문에 안 될 것 같아요’라고 하면, 그 사람 때문에 일이 그냥 느려질 뿐이에요.
text_zh: 所以'Deel速度'对我们来说特别特别重要。这也是我们对团队成员的期望，大家都要做到这一点。就是要想，我怎么能最快地把这个问题解决好？然后不断地推自己，做事要有紧迫感。我们还很看重保持积极的态度。我们有一种天然的乐观主义，因为我们做的是新领域，所以如果有人来到Deel，然后很悲观，总是说'我觉得这个不行，因为这样那样的原因'，这样的人只会拖慢我们的节奏。
text_es: Entonces la 'velocidad Deel' es súper importante para nosotros. Y eso es algo que esperamos de los miembros del equipo que se comprometen con esto. Que se pregunten: ¿cuál es la forma más rápida de resolver este problema bien? Y que constantemente se presionen a sí mismos para actuar con urgencia. También nos importa mantenernos positivos. Tenemos optimismo por defecto porque estamos en un espacio nuevo, entonces si alguien va a llegar a Deel y va a ser pesimista y dice 'no creo que eso vaya a funcionar por tal, tal y tal razón,' simplemente va a ralentizar las cosas.
context: Lenny asks about Deel's culture and how it compares to other fast-growing startups. Meltem explains two key cultural values at Deel: 'Deel speed' (acting with urgency) and 'default optimism' (staying positive and solution-focused). She explains that because they're in a new market space, they need people who approach challenges with a can-do attitude rather than immediately focusing on why things won't work, as pessimism slows down progress.
vocabulary_highlights: act with urgency, default optimism, slow things down

speaker: Merci Grace
text: Yeah, I got into product accidentally. I was first a game designer and actually started a venture-backed game studio right after college when I had absolutely no idea what I was doing. I got my first term sheet as a founder before I knew what venture capital was. Purely accidental. And it's funny because my career arc went founder, game designer, product management, VC, CEO of your own startup, something that people try to do on purpose now, and I was not trying to do it on purpose at all.
text_ko: 저는 우연히 제품 분야에 들어갔어요. 처음에는 게임 디자이너였고, 대학 졸업 후에 아무것도 모른 채로 벤처 자금을 받은 게임 스튜디오를 시작했거든요. 벤처 캐피탈이 뭔지도 모르고 창립자로서 첫 번째 계약서(term sheet)를 받았어요. 정말 순전히 우연이었죠. 그리고 제 경력 궤적이 창립자, 게임 디자이너, 제품 관리, VC, 그리고 결국에는 자신의 스타트업 CEO가 되었는데, 요즘 사람들은 이런 걸 의도적으로 하려고 하잖아요. 저는 전혀 그런 의도가 없었어요.
text_zh: 其实我进入产品这行完全是个意外。我最开始是做游戏设计的，大学一毕业就搞了个拿风投的游戏工作室，那时候真的是啥都不懂。我作为创始人拿到第一份投资意向书(term sheet)的时候，连风险投资(venture capital)是什么都不知道，纯属瞎猫碰死耗子。现在想想挺好笑的，我的职业路径是创始人、游戏设计师、产品经理、投资人、再到自己创业当CEO，这套路线现在很多人都想故意这么走，但我当时完全没想过要这样规划。
text_es: Sí, llegué al mundo del producto por casualidad. Primero era diseñador de videojuegos y de hecho monté un estudio de juegos con capital de riesgo justo después de la universidad, cuando no tenía ni idea de lo que estaba haciendo. Me dieron mi primera propuesta de inversión (term sheet) como fundador antes de saber siquiera qué era el capital de riesgo. Pura casualidad. Y es gracioso porque mi trayectoria profesional fue: fundador, diseñador de juegos, gestión de producto, inversionista de riesgo, CEO de tu propia startup - algo que la gente ahora trata de hacer a propósito, pero yo para nada lo estaba haciendo intencionalmente.
context: Lenny asks Merci about her career journey and how she got into product management, given her diverse background as founder, game designer, head of product and growth at Slack, VC, and now founder again. Merci explains that her career progression wasn't intentional - she simply followed her curiosity about how people think and make decisions. Her path of founder to game designer to product management to VC to CEO is now something entrepreneurs deliberately pursue, but for her it was completely organic and unplanned.
vocabulary_highlights: purely accidental, career arc, on purpose

speaker: Merci Grace
text: I think one of the things that is quite obvious from the get-go, when you have had a few months under your belt, you've been seeing a bunch of pitches, and seeing the one-on-one pitches and then seeing the partner meeting pitches, is how different really great CEOs and startup leaders are at storytelling, at coming up with a pithy answer, at owning the room.
text_ko: 제 생각엔 몇 달 동안 경험을 쌓으면서 여러 피치(pitches)를 보고, 일대일(one-on-one) 피치와 파트너 미팅(partner meeting) 피치까지 접해 보면, 처음부터 확실히 드러나는 것 중 하나가 정말 뛰어난 CEO들과 스타트업 리더들은 스토리텔링(storytelling), 짧고 임팩트 있는 답변(pithy answer), 그리고 현장을 장악하는 능력(owning the room)에서 확연히 다르다는 점이에요.
text_zh: 我觉得有一点特别明显，就是当你干了几个月，听了很多项目路演(pitch)，包括一对一的和合伙人会议上的，你就会发现那些真正优秀的CEO和创业领袖在讲故事、给出精准回答、还有控场方面真的很不一样。
text_es: Creo que una de las cosas que se nota desde el primer día, cuando ya llevas unos meses en esto, has visto un montón de presentaciones, tanto las reuniones uno a uno como las que se hacen con los socios, es lo diferentes que son los CEOs y líderes de startups realmente buenos para contar historias, para dar respuestas precisas y contundentes, para dominar completamente la sala.
context: Lenny asks what Merci learned during her time as a VC that surprised her as a founder. Merci explains that after observing many startup pitches in both one-on-one and partner meeting settings, she realized that exceptional CEOs stand out primarily through their communication skills rather than just business fundamentals. Great founders excel at crafting compelling narratives, delivering concise responses, and commanding presence in high-stakes presentations.
vocabulary_highlights: from the get-go, under your belt, pithy answer, owning the room

speaker: Merci Grace
text: And honestly, looking at things like movies and TV shows, every pitch should start in the middle of the action, like a thriller or like a drama, like Mission Impossible movies always start with Tom cruise doing some crazy shit in the middle of the job right before the job that the actual movie is about because it gets your attention. And so I think that's one of the things that people often try to fit whatever the template they think is. And often in business, it ends up being, 'Oh, what's this more staid, boring way to say this?'
text_ko: 솔직히 영화나 TV를 보면 모든 피치(pitch)는 바로 액션 한가운데서 시작해야 해요. 스릴러나 드라마처럼요. 미션 임파서블(Mission: Impossible) 같은 영화들이 항상 본편에서 다룰 임무 바로 직전에 톰 크루즈가 임무 도중 엄청난 일을 벌이는 장면으로 시작하는 것도 사람들의 관심을 확 끌기 때문이에요. 그래서 사람들은 자꾸 어떤 템플릿(template)에 맞추려 하고, 비즈니스에서는 흔히 ‘이걸 좀 더 점잖고 지루한 방식으로 어떻게 말하지?’ 하는 식으로 끝내버리곤 해요.
text_zh: 说实话，你看那些电影电视剧，每个提案(pitch)都应该从最精彩的部分开始，就像惊悚片或者剧情片一样。你看《碟中谍》系列，汤姆·克鲁斯总是一开场就在干一些疯狂的事儿，都是在正片开始前的任务中间，因为这样最抓人眼球。我觉得很多人的问题就是总想套什么模板。特别是在商业场合，经常就变成了"哎，怎么用更正经、更无聊的方式来说这件事？"
text_es: Y la verdad, si te fijas en las películas y series de TV, toda presentación debería empezar en medio de la acción, como un thriller o un drama. Las películas de Misión Imposible siempre arrancan con Tom Cruise haciendo alguna locura en pleno trabajo, justo antes del trabajo principal de la película, porque eso te engancha de inmediato. Y creo que ese es uno de los problemas: la gente siempre trata de encajar en el molde que cree que debe usar. Y muchas veces en los negocios terminamos pensando: "¿Cuál será la forma más aburrida y formal de decir esto?"
context: Lenny asks for tactical advice on improving storytelling and presentation skills for founders. Merci recommends that founders structure their pitches like compelling entertainment - starting with the most exciting, attention-grabbing element rather than following traditional business presentation templates. She uses Mission Impossible movies as an example, where the opening action sequence hooks the audience before revealing the main plot. This approach helps founders avoid the trap of creating overly formal, boring business presentations.
vocabulary_highlights: in the middle of the action, more staid, crazy shit

speaker: Merci Grace
text: There was this internal campaign that was very irritating to me at the time from people saying, 'We absolutely need to allow people to block each other on Slack.' All these people who are using open source communities, all these different sort of use cases for it. And I went on a bit of a rant, I would call it in... I think it was our culture channel, which was its own sort of total shit show, but this channel where people would this meta thinking about Slack.
text_ko: 그때 내부적으로 “우리는 반드시 사람들이 슬랙(Slack)에서 서로 차단할 수 있게 해야 해”라고 주장하는 캠페인이 있었는데, 그게 저한테는 정말 짜증났어요. 오픈 소스 커뮤니티(open source communities)를 쓰는 사람들 등 다양한 사용 사례가 있다는 식이었죠. 그래서 저는 거기서 좀 툴툴거리면서 불만을 토로했어요. 아마 우리 '컬처' 채널(culture channel)이었던 것 같은데, 그 채널 자체가 완전 난장판이었고 사람들이 슬랙에 대해 이런저런 메타 얘기를 나누는 곳이었어요.
text_zh: 当时有个内部讨论特别让我头疼，一堆人在那说"我们绝对得让用户在Slack上互相屏蔽对方"。说什么开源社区的用户啊，各种使用场景啊。然后我就在...我记得是在我们文化频道里发了通牢骚，那个频道本身就是一团糟，但大家都在那讨论关于Slack的各种想法。
text_es: Hubo una campaña interna que me tenía súper molesto en ese momento, con gente diciendo: "Absolutamente tenemos que permitir que la gente se bloquee entre sí en Slack." Toda esta gente que usa comunidades de código abierto (open source), todos estos casos de uso diferentes. Y me lancé en una especie de descarga, yo le diría... creo que fue en nuestro canal de cultura, que era su propio desmadre total, pero este canal donde la gente hacía este pensamiento meta (meta thinking) sobre Slack.
context: Lenny asks what most people don't know about Slack. Merci explains that internally at Slack around 2015, it wasn't obvious to everyone that Slack was specifically a workplace tool rather than a social platform. She describes pushback she received from employees who wanted to add blocking features to accommodate social use cases like open source communities. This led to internal debates about product direction, with Merci arguing against blocking features because they weren't appropriate for workplace collaboration.
vocabulary_highlights: went on a bit of a rant, total shit show, meta thinking

speaker: Merci Grace
text: Yeah. I think one of the best things that we did is that we really started with curiosity first, and we weren't like, 'Okay, here are all of our baseline metrics. We already know what's important. Let's just do this.' Because April Underwood, former CPO at Slack, had this great line that she would say internally, which is, 'No one has built Slack before.' I really loved that as this kind of mental starting place where it's like, there isn't going to be this cookie cutter thing.
text_ko: 네. 우리가 잘한 것 중 하나는 정말 호기심에서 출발했다는 거예요. 그리고 ‘자, 여기 우리 기본 지표들(baseline metrics)이 있고 이미 중요한 걸 다 알고 있으니 이걸 하자’ 식으로 시작하지 않았어요. 슬랙의 전 CPO(Chief Product Officer)였던 April Underwood는 내부에서 이런 멋진 말을 하곤 했는데, “아무도 슬랙을 전에 만들어본 적이 없다”고요. 저는 그 말이 ‘틀에 박힌 정답은 없다’는 마음가짐으로 시작하게 해줘서 정말 마음에 들었어요.
text_zh: 对，我觉得我们做得最好的一点就是，我们真的是从好奇心出发的，而不是说"好，这些就是我们的基准指标，我们已经知道什么重要了，就按这个做吧。"因为April Underwood，Slack的前CPO，她有句话在内部经常说，就是"以前没人做过Slack这样的产品。"我特别喜欢这种思维起点，就是说，不会有什么现成的套路可以照搬。
text_es: Sí, totalmente. Creo que una de las mejores cosas que hicimos fue empezar desde la curiosidad, ¿sabes? No llegamos con la actitud de "bueno, aquí están todas nuestras métricas base, ya sabemos qué es lo importante, simplemente hagamos esto." Porque April Underwood, que fue CPO en Slack, tenía una frase genial que siempre decía internamente: "Nadie ha construido Slack antes." Me encantaba esa idea como punto de partida mental, porque realmente no iba a haber una fórmula mágica que aplicar.
context: Lenny asks what Merci learned from growing Slack that could apply to other user-first, product-led companies. Merci explains that Slack's growth team approached their work with genuine curiosity rather than assuming they knew what metrics mattered most. The CPO April Underwood's phrase "No one has built Slack before" became their guiding philosophy, emphasizing that they couldn't simply copy existing playbooks and needed to discover what worked specifically for their unique product and users.
vocabulary_highlights: curiosity first, cookie cutter thing, mental starting place
topics: Growth & Marketing, Product Management, Strategy & Planning

speaker: Merci Grace
text: One of the big ones in that regard is the understanding that there are people who are just more social, right? I'm sure you're this kind of person. You're a connector and you know a lot of people, you love introducing them, bringing them together. We are who we are, fundamentally. And so within any population, including a user base, there will be people who are more likely to invite other people to the product or to bring people around into it, especially if it's something like a collaboration product.
text_ko: 그런 점에서 큰 것 중 하나는 단순히 더 사교적인 사람들이 있다는 걸 이해하는 거예요. 분명 당신도 그런 타입일 거예요 — 커넥터(connector)라서 사람도 많이 알고, 사람 소개해 주는 걸 좋아하고, 사람들끼리 연결하는 걸 즐기잖아요. 근본적으로 사람은 제각각이에요. 그래서 어떤 집단 안에는, 사용자 기반(user base)을 포함해서, 다른 사람들을 제품으로 초대하거나 제품으로 끌어들이는 경향이 더 큰 사람들이 있게 마련이에요. 특히 협업 제품(collaboration product) 같은 경우에는 더 그렇죠.
text_zh: 这方面有个很重要的认知就是，有些人天生就比较社交，对吧？我相信你就是这种人。你是个连接者(connector)，认识很多人，喜欢给大家做介绍，把人聚到一起。我们就是我们，本性难移嘛。所以在任何人群里，包括用户群体，肯定会有那些更愿意邀请别人来用产品的人，或者把身边的人都拉进来，特别是如果这是个协作类产品的话。
text_es: Una de las cosas clave en este sentido es entender que hay gente que simplemente es más sociable, ¿no? Seguro que tú eres de este tipo de personas. Eres un conector (connector) y conoces a mucha gente, te encanta presentarlos, juntarlos. Somos como somos, básicamente. Y entonces dentro de cualquier grupo de usuarios, va a haber personas que tienen más probabilidades de invitar a otros al producto o de traer gente, sobre todo si es algo como un producto de colaboración.
context: Lenny asks about lessons from growing Slack that apply to other prosumer, product-led, bottom-up products. Merci explains that some users are naturally more social and likely to invite others to products, especially collaboration tools. Rather than trying to convert everyone into inviters, it's more effective to focus on these naturally social users who are connectors and enjoy bringing people together. This insight helped shape Slack's growth strategy around identifying and empowering these key user personas.
vocabulary_highlights: in that regard, bring people around into it, fundamentally

speaker: Michael Truell
speaker_expertise: AI/ML Products, Product Strategy, Company Building
text: One is, there's a group of people who think that software building in the future is going to look very much like it does today, which mostly means text editing, formal programming languages, like TypeScript, and Go, and C, and Rust. And then there's another group that kind of thinks you're just going to type into a bot, and you're going to ask it to build you something, and then you're going to ask it to change something about what you're building, and it's kind of like this chatbot, Slackbot style where you're talking to your engineering department. And we think that there are problems with both of those visions.
text_ko: 한쪽에는 앞으로 소프트웨어 개발이 지금과 거의 똑같을 거라고 보는 사람들이 있어요. 그 말은 대부분 텍스트 편집(text editing)과 정형화된 프로그래밍 언어(TypeScript, Go, C, Rust)로 작업하는 방식이라는 뜻이에요. 다른 한쪽은 그냥 봇(bot)에게 타이핑해서 뭔가를 만들어 달라고 하고, 그 만든 것에 대해 바꿔 달라고 말하면 되는 식일 거라고 생각해요 — 일종의 챗봇(chatbot), 슬랙봇(Slackbot) 스타일로 엔지니어링 부서(engineering department)랑 대화하듯이요. 저희는 그 두 가지 전망 모두에 문제점이 있다고 생각해요.
text_zh: 一种观点是，有一群人认为未来的软件开发基本上还会和现在差不多，主要就是编辑文本，用正式的编程语言，比如TypeScript、Go、C和Rust这些。另一种观点呢，有些人觉得以后你就直接跟机器人聊天就行了，让它帮你做个什么东西，然后再让它改改这改改那的，就像跟聊天机器人(chatbot)或者Slack机器人(Slackbot)对话一样，感觉像是在跟你们工程部门聊天似的。我们觉得这两种想法都有问题。
text_es: Mira, hay un grupo de gente que piensa que el desarrollo de software en el futuro va a ser muy parecido a como es hoy en día, o sea, básicamente editando texto, usando lenguajes de programación formales como TypeScript, Go, C y Rust. Y después está el otro grupo que más bien cree que simplemente vas a escribirle a un bot, le vas a pedir que te construya algo, y luego le vas a decir que le cambie tal o cual cosa a lo que estás desarrollando, como si fuera un chatbot estilo Slackbot donde estás hablando con tu departamento de ingeniería. Y nosotros creemos que ambas visiones tienen sus problemas.
context: Lenny asks Michael about his vision of 'what comes after code' - essentially how programming will evolve beyond current methods. Michael is explaining why he disagrees with two popular visions for the future of software development. He argues that one camp thinks nothing will change from today's text-based coding, while another camp believes everything will be done through chatbot-style interactions with AI.
vocabulary_highlights: formal programming languages, chatbot, Slackbot style, both of those visions

speaker: Michael Truell
speaker_expertise: AI/ML Products, Product Strategy, Company Building
text: And so a world after code, I think that it looks like a world where you have a representation of the logic of your software that does look more like English, you have written down... You can imagine in [inaudible] form, you can imagine in kind of an evolution of programming language towards pseudocode. You have written down the logic of the software, and you can edit that at a high level, and you can point at that.
text_ko: 제가 보기에는 코드(code) 이후의 세상은 소프트웨어(software) 로직을 더 영어처럼 보이는 형태로 표현해 둔 게 있고, 그걸 적어놓을 수 있는 세상이에요. 어떤 방식으로든 프로그래밍 언어(programming language)가 의사 코드(pseudocode) 쪽으로 진화한 모습을 상상할 수 있고, 소프트웨어 로직을 적어두고 그것을 고수준(high level)에서 편집할 수 있으며, 그냥 가리키기만 해서 수정할 수도 있어요.
text_zh: 所以我觉得后代码时代(post-code)的世界，应该是这样的：你的软件逻辑表达会更像英语，你把逻辑写下来...你可以想象成某种形式，也可以想象成编程语言朝着伪代码(pseudocode)方向的演进。你把软件的逻辑写出来，然后可以在高层面上编辑，也可以直接指向那些逻辑。
text_es: Y entonces, un mundo después del código, yo creo que se ve como un mundo donde tienes una representación de la lógica de tu software que se parece más al inglés, donde has escrito... Te puedes imaginar de forma [inaudible], te puedes imaginar como una evolución del lenguaje de programación hacia pseudocódigo. Has escrito la lógica del software, y puedes editarla a alto nivel, y puedes señalarla directamente.
context: Lenny is asking Michael to elaborate on his concept of 'what comes after code.' Michael is describing his vision where programming evolves from today's complex code syntax to something more human-readable, resembling English or pseudocode. This represents his prediction for how software development will fundamentally change as AI capabilities improve.
vocabulary_highlights: world after code, evolution of programming language towards pseudocode, edit that at a high level

speaker: Michael Truell
speaker_expertise: AI/ML Products, Product Strategy, Company Building
text: I think taste will be increasingly more valuable. And I think often when people think about tastes in the realm of software, they think about visuals, or taste over smooth animations, and coloring things, UI, UX, et cetera on the visual design of things. And the visual side of things is an important part of defining a piece of software, but then, as mentioned before, I think that the other half of defining a piece of software is the logic of it, and how the thing works.
text_ko: 앞으로 미적 감각의 가치가 점점 더 커질 거예요. 그리고 소프트웨어에서의 감각을 말할 때 사람들은 보통 시각적 요소, 즉 부드러운 애니메이션(smooth animations)이나 색채 처리, 사용자 인터페이스(UI), 사용자 경험(UX) 같은 시각적 디자인(visual design)부터 떠올리는 경우가 많아요. 시각적 측면이 소프트웨어를 정의하는 데 중요한 부분인 건 맞지만, 앞서 말한 것처럼 나머지 절반은 그 소프트웨어의 로직(logic), 즉 실제로 어떻게 작동하느냐에 있다고 생각해요.
text_zh: 我觉得品味会越来越值钱。说到软件的品味，大家往往想到的是视觉效果，比如流畅的动画啊，配色啊，UI、UX这些视觉设计方面的东西。视觉确实是定义一个软件很重要的部分，但就像我刚才说的，我觉得定义软件的另一半是它的逻辑，也就是这个东西到底怎么运作的。
text_es: Creo que el buen gusto va a ser cada vez más valioso. Y me parece que cuando la gente piensa en el gusto en el mundo del software, se enfocan en lo visual, o en el gusto por las animaciones fluidas, los colores, la UI, UX, etcétera, todo lo relacionado con el diseño visual. Y sí, la parte visual es importante para definir un software, pero como mencioné antes, creo que la otra mitad de lo que define un software es la lógica detrás, cómo funciona realmente la cosa.
context: Lenny asks what skills will become more valuable in the future world where coding evolves beyond traditional programming languages. Michael explains that 'taste' - the ability to make good decisions about what should be built - will become increasingly important. He argues that taste applies not just to visual design elements, but also to the underlying logic and functionality of software.
vocabulary_highlights: taste will be increasingly more valuable, in the realm of software, the other half of defining

speaker: Michael Truell
speaker_expertise: AI/ML Products, Product Strategy, Company Building
text: And so I think that more and more, being an engineer will start to feel like being a logic designer, and really, it will be about specifying your intent for how exactly you want everything to work. It'd be more about the whats, and a little bit less about how exactly you're going to do things under the hood.
text_ko: 그래서 점점 엔지니어라는 일이 논리 디자이너(logic designer)처럼 느껴질 것 같아요. 실제로는 모든 것이 정확히 어떻게 동작하길 원하는지 의도를 명확히 하는 일이 될 거예요. 무엇을 할지(what)에 더 집중하고, 내부에서 어떻게 구체적으로 구현할지(under the hood)에는 좀 덜 신경 쓰게 될 거예요.
text_zh: 所以我觉得，工程师这个职业会越来越像做逻辑设计师，关键是要把你的想法说清楚——你到底想要什么样的效果。重点会放在"要什么结果"上，而不是纠结底层具体怎么实现。
text_es: Y entonces creo que cada vez más, ser ingeniero va a empezar a sentirse como ser un diseñador de lógica, y en realidad, va a tratarse de especificar tu intención de cómo exactamente quieres que funcione todo. Va a ser más sobre los qués, y un poco menos sobre cómo exactamente vas a hacer las cosas por debajo del capó (under the hood).
context: Lenny is asking about what skills will be valuable as programming evolves beyond traditional code. Michael is explaining how the role of software engineers will transform - instead of focusing on the technical implementation details ('how'), engineers will focus more on defining the desired outcomes and logic ('what'). He uses the term 'logic designer' to describe this future role.
vocabulary_highlights: logic designer, specifying your intent, under the hood

speaker: Michael Truell
speaker_expertise: AI/ML Products, Product Strategy, Company Building
text: I think that vibe coding right now describes exactly this state of creation that is pretty controversial, where you're generating a lot of coding, you aren't really understanding the details. That is a state of creation that then has lots of problems, you don't really... By not understanding the details under the hood right now, you then very quickly get to a place where you're kind of limited at a certain point, where you create something that's big enough that you can't change.
text_ko: 지금 '바이브 코딩(vibe coding)'이라는 표현이 바로 이런 꽤 논란이 되는 만드는 상태를 정확히 설명한다고 생각해요. 코드를 엄청 많이 생성하긴 하는데 내부 구조(under the hood) 같은 세부를 제대로 이해하진 못하는 거죠. 그런 방식은 나중에 여러 문제를 만들어요. 세부를 모른 채로 가다 보면 금방 한계에 부딪히고, 어느 순간엔 너무 커져서 변경하기 어려운 걸 만들게 돼요.
