text_zh: 我觉得现在这种氛围编程(vibe coding)说的就是这么一种创作状态，挺有争议的，就是你能生成大量代码，但其实你并不真正理解细节。这种创作状态问题很多，你不是真的...因为不了解底层的具体原理，你很快就会遇到瓶颈，到了某个点就被卡住了，你做出来的东西太大太复杂，根本没法改。
text_es: Creo que lo que llaman "vibe coding" describe perfectamente este estado de creación que genera bastante polémica, donde estás produciendo un montón de código pero realmente no entiendes los detalles. Es un estado de creación que trae muchos problemas después, porque al no entender lo que está pasando por debajo, llegas muy rápido a un punto donde te quedas limitado, donde creates algo tan grande que ya no lo puedes cambiar.
context: Lenny asks if Michael's vision relates to 'vibe coding' - a controversial programming approach where developers generate code quickly without fully understanding the technical details. Michael explains that while vibe coding represents a new state of creation, it currently has limitations because when you don't understand the underlying implementation, you eventually hit barriers where you can't modify or scale your creation effectively.
vocabulary_highlights: vibe coding, state of creation, under the hood, limited at a certain point

speaker: Michael Truell
speaker_expertise: AI/ML Products, Product Strategy, Company Building
text: We definitely didn't expect to be doing any of our own model development when we started. As mentioned, when we got into this, there were companies that were immediately from the get-go going and just focusing on training model from scratch. And we had done the calculation for what it to train before, and just knew that that was not going to be able to do. And also felt a bit like focusing one's attention in the wrong area, because there were lots of amazing models out there, and why develop all this work to replicate what other players had done.
text_ko: 처음 시작할 때 우리가 직접 모델 개발(model development)을 하게 될 줄은 전혀 몰랐어요. 말씀드린 것처럼, 우리가 이 분야에 들어왔을 때는 어떤 회사들이 시작부터 처음부터 학습시키는(training models from scratch)에만 바로 전념하고 있었죠. 우리는 모델을 학습시키는 데 드는 비용과 시간 등을 계산해봤고, 우리로선 그걸 감당할 수 없을 거라는 결론이었어요. 또 주의를 잘못된 곳에 두는 것 같다는 느낌도 들었어요. 이미 훌륭한 모델들이 많은데, 다른 플레이어들이 해놓은 걸 똑같이 복제하기 위해 그 많은 노력을 들일 이유가 없으니까요.
text_zh: 我们一开始真的没想过要自己搞模型开发。就像前面说的，当时我们刚入行的时候，已经有不少公司从一开始就专门做从零训练模型这块。我们之前算过从头训练模型要花多少钱，就知道我们肯定搞不起。而且我们也觉得把注意力放在这上面有点跑偏了，因为市面上已经有很多很棒的模型了，为什么还要花那么大力气去重复别人已经做过的事情呢。
text_es: Definitivamente no esperábamos acabar desarrollando nuestros propios modelos cuando empezamos. Como mencioné, cuando nos metimos en esto, había empresas que desde el primer día se lanzaron a entrenar modelos desde cero. Ya habíamos calculado lo que costaba entrenar antes, y sabíamos que eso no lo íbamos a poder hacer. Y también sentíamos que era como enfocar la atención en el lugar equivocado, porque había un montón de modelos increíbles por ahí, y para qué desarrollar todo ese trabajo para replicar lo que otros ya habían hecho.
context: Lenny asks about the most counterintuitive lesson Michael learned while building Cursor. Michael explains that they initially planned to rely entirely on existing AI models from other companies, believing it would be inefficient to replicate work that had already been done. However, they eventually discovered that custom model development became essential for creating the best user experience, which was unexpected given their original strategy.
vocabulary_highlights: from the get-go, done the calculation, focusing one's attention in the wrong area, replicate what other players had done

speaker: Michael Truell
speaker_expertise: AI/ML Products, Product Strategy, Company Building
text: And at this point, every magic moment in Cursor involves a custom model in some way. So that was definitely counterintuitive, and surprising, and it's been a gradual thing, where there was an initial use case for training our own model, where it really didn't make sense to use any of the biggest foundation models. That was incredibly successful, moved to another use case that worked really well, and had been going from there.
text_ko: 지금은 Cursor의 모든 매직 모먼트(magic moment)에 어떤 식으로든 맞춤형 모델(custom model)이 들어가 있어요. 그래서 처음엔 확실히 직관에 반하는 일이라 놀랐어요. 이건 점진적으로 이뤄진 변화인데, 초반에는 자체 모델을 학습시키는 초기 사용 사례(initial use case)가 있었고 그때는 가장 큰 파운데이션 모델들(foundation models)을 쓰는 게 전혀 말이 안 됐어요. 그게 엄청 성공했고, 그다음엔 또 잘 맞는 다른 사용 사례로 옮겨가서 잘 작동했어요. 그 이후로는 계속 그런 식으로 발전해왔어요.
text_zh: 现在Cursor里每个让人眼前一亮的功能，背后都离不开我们自己训练的模型。说实话，这确实挺反直觉的，也挺出人意料的。这是个循序渐进的过程，一开始我们遇到一个使用场景，用那些大的基础模型根本不合适，只能自己训练模型。结果效果出奇的好，然后我们又在另一个场景试了试，也很成功，就这样一步步做下来的。
text_es: Y en este punto, cada momento mágico en Cursor involucra un modelo personalizado de alguna manera. Así que definitivamente fue algo contraintuitivo y sorprendente, y ha sido algo gradual, donde hubo un caso de uso inicial para entrenar nuestro propio modelo, donde realmente no tenía sentido usar ninguno de los modelos fundacionales (foundation models) más grandes. Eso fue increíblemente exitoso, pasamos a otro caso de uso que funcionó muy bien, y desde ahí hemos seguido avanzando.
context: Lenny asks about counterintuitive lessons from building Cursor. Michael is continuing his explanation about how they unexpectedly ended up developing their own AI models despite initially planning to rely on existing ones. He reveals that every impressive feature ('magic moment') in Cursor now uses some form of custom model, and this transition happened gradually as they found specific use cases where custom models significantly outperformed existing foundation models.
vocabulary_highlights: every magic moment, counterintuitive, gradual thing, foundation models

speaker: Mihika Kapoor
speaker_expertise: Product Management, Product Strategy, Product Design
text: My take is that vision is everything. It is really important to create a vision that you believe in, that your team believes in and that your company believes in. Because the reality of the product development cycle is that it's so messy, it's so chaotic. You're going to have extreme highs and extreme lows.
text_ko: 제 생각에는 비전(vision)이 전부예요. 제가 믿고 팀과 회사도 함께 믿을 수 있는 비전을 만드는 게 정말 중요해요. 제품 개발 주기(product development cycle)의 현실은 실제로 너무 어수선하고 혼란스러워요. 그래서 큰 성공과 큰 실패를 번갈아 겪게 될 거예요.
text_zh: 我的看法是，愿景就是一切。打造一个你自己信、团队信、公司上下都信的愿景，这真的太重要了。因为产品开发这个过程啊，现实就是特别乱，特别混乱。你肯定会经历大起大落，高潮低谷都很极端。
text_es: Mi punto de vista es que la visión lo es todo. Es súper importante crear una visión en la que realmente creas, en la que tu equipo crea y en la que cree toda la empresa. Porque la realidad del ciclo de desarrollo de producto es que está hecho un lío, es un caos total. Vas a tener momentos increíbles y momentos terribles.
context: Lenny asks Mihika about creating compelling visions and getting buy-in for big ideas, referencing feedback from her VP of Product about her exceptional vision-crafting abilities. Mihika explains why having a strong vision is foundational to successful product development. She emphasizes that the product development cycle involves constant ups and downs, pivots based on user feedback, and chaotic changes, making it essential to have an anchoring vision that keeps the team focused on forward progress rather than getting discouraged by setbacks.
vocabulary_highlights: extreme highs and extreme lows, so messy, it's so chaotic
topics: Product Management, Leadership & Management, Strategy & Planning

speaker: Mihika Kapoor
speaker_expertise: Product Management, Product Strategy, Product Design
text: We lean heavily into designing and prototyping even before a project gets a green light. So, I think that's something that's really unique about Figma is normally you will talk about the market space or the opportunity of the sizing, and then decide to invest. Versus Figma is very much a see to believe and see to feel that emotional pull towards this is something worth investing in.
text_ko: 프로젝트가 본격적으로 승인(그린 라이트)되기 전에도 디자인과 프로토타이핑(prototyping)에 적극적으로 집중해요. 보통은 시장 공간(market space)이나 기회와 규모를 따져보고 투자를 결정하는데, Figma는 직접 보고 믿는 방식(see to believe)과 직접 보고 느껴야 마음이 끌리는 방식(see to feel)으로 투자가치가 있는지 실감하게 만드는 점이 정말 독특한 것 같아요.
text_zh: 我们在项目还没正式批准之前就会大力投入设计和做原型。所以我觉得Figma真正独特的地方在于，通常大家都是先谈市场空间啊、机会规模什么的，然后再决定要不要投。但Figma完全不一样，我们是要看得见摸得着，要能感受到那种情感上的冲动，觉得"这个真的值得投"。
text_es: Nosotros apostamos fuerte al diseño y a los prototipos incluso antes de que un proyecto tenga luz verde. Entonces, creo que eso es algo realmente único de Figma: normalmente hablas del mercado o del tamaño de la oportunidad, y después decides invertir. En cambio, Figma es muy de "ver para creer" y ver para sentir esa conexión emocional de que esto vale la pena como inversión.
context: Lenny asks how to actually deliver a compelling vision, noting that many people struggle with creating more than just written descriptions. Mihika explains Figma's approach to vision-making, which differs from traditional methods. Instead of starting with market analysis and opportunity sizing before deciding to invest, Figma creates visual prototypes and designs early in the process to help stakeholders emotionally connect with the idea and truly understand its potential impact.
vocabulary_highlights: lean heavily into, gets a green light, see to believe, emotional pull towards

speaker: Mihika Kapoor
speaker_expertise: Product Management, Product Strategy, Product Design
text: We have this concept called Maker Week, which is our internal hackathon, where the entire company goes on pause for a week. And I think that most people think that, 'Oh, hackathons are only a time for engineers to build.' And I think that that's one of the biggest mistakes ever. I think that anyone can have an idea and can... Literally, what I did was walk around the New York office asking every single person, 'Will you work on this thing with me?'
text_ko: 저희는 메이커 위크(Maker Week)라는 개념이 있어요. 내부 해커톤(hackathon)으로 회사 전체가 일주일 동안 잠시 멈추는 시간이죠. 대부분 사람들은 '해커톤은 엔지니어들만 무언가를 만드는 시간이다'라고 생각하는데, 그건 정말 큰 오해예요. 누구나 아이디어를 내고 참여할 수 있어요. 말 그대로 제가 한 건 뉴욕 오피스를 돌아다니며 한 사람 한 사람에게 '이거 같이 해줄래요?'라고 물어본 거예요.
text_zh: 我们有个叫"创客周"(Maker Week)的概念，就是我们内部的黑客马拉松(hackathon)，整个公司会停下手头的事专门搞一周。我觉得大多数人都以为，"哦，黑客马拉松就是给工程师搭建东西的时候"。我觉得这是最大的误区之一。我认为任何人都可以有想法，都可以...说白了，我当时就是在纽约办公室里到处转悠，逮着每个人问，"你愿意和我一起搞这个项目吗？"
text_es: Tenemos este concepto que se llama Maker Week, que es nuestro hackathon interno, donde toda la empresa se pone en pausa por una semana. Y creo que la mayoría de la gente piensa que, 'Ay, los hackathons son solo para que los ingenieros desarrollen cosas.' Y me parece que ese es uno de los errores más grandes que hay. Yo creo que cualquiera puede tener una idea y puede... Literalmente, lo que hice fue caminar por toda la oficina de Nueva York preguntándole a cada persona, '¿Te animas a trabajar en esto conmigo?'
context: Lenny asks for advice on how to create compelling visions when you don't have design or engineering skills yourself. Mihika shares how she used Figma's internal hackathon called Maker Week to build momentum for her product idea. She explains that hackathons aren't just for engineers - anyone can participate by finding collaborators and building teams around their ideas, emphasizing the importance of not letting skill limitations prevent you from pursuing compelling product concepts.
vocabulary_highlights: goes on pause, one of the biggest mistakes ever, walk around
topics: Product Management, Starting a Company, Networking

speaker: Mihika Kapoor
speaker_expertise: Product Management, Product Strategy, Product Design
text: I'm a huge proponent of Jeff Bezos's one-way doors, two-way doors framework. And I think that especially in a software company, most things are two-way doors. You can come back. And so, it's so important to have an opinion and use that opinion to anchor people around and have people react to.
text_ko: 저는 제프 베조스의 일방향 문(one-way doors)과 양방향 문(two-way doors) 프레임워크를 적극적으로 지지해요. 특히 소프트웨어 회사에서는 대부분의 것들이 양방향 문이라서 다시 되돌아올 수 있어요. 그래서 의견을 분명히 갖고 그걸 기준으로 사람들을 모으고 반응을 이끌어내는 게 정말 중요해요.
text_zh: 我特别认同贝佐斯那套单向门、双向门的理念。我觉得在软件公司，大部分事情都是双向门，你随时可以回头嘛。所以特别重要的是，你得有自己的观点，用这个观点把大家凝聚起来，让大家有个反应的基础。
text_es: Soy un gran defensor del marco de Jeff Bezos sobre las puertas de ida y las puertas de ida y vuelta (one-way doors, two-way doors). Y creo que especialmente en una empresa de software, la mayoría de las cosas son puertas de ida y vuelta. Puedes regresar. Y por eso es súper importante tener una opinión y usar esa opinión para que la gente se alinee contigo y reaccione.
context: Lenny asks Mihika about how she develops such strong conviction so quickly, based on feedback from Figma's CPO. Mihika explains her approach to building conviction and momentum for product decisions. She references Jeff Bezos's framework that distinguishes between irreversible decisions (one-way doors) and reversible ones (two-way doors). In software companies, most decisions can be undone, so she advocates for having strong opinions that give teams something concrete to react to and build upon, rather than starting from nothing.
vocabulary_highlights: huge proponent of, anchor people around, have people react to
topics: Product Management, Decision Making, Leadership & Management

speaker: Mihika Kapoor
speaker_expertise: Product Management, Product Strategy, Product Design
text: My take is that putting out an idea, even if it's totally wrong, is a much better catalyst for getting to a good solution because people are much more likely to react to an idea than to nothing. So, if it's the right idea, then they'll be like, 'Oh my God, yes, let's totally do that.' And if it's wrong, then it's like, okay, then they will take you in a different direction.
text_ko: 제 생각엔 아이디어를 내보는 게 설령 완전히 틀렸더라도 좋은 해결책으로 가는 촉매(catalyst)가 돼요. 사람들은 아무것도 없는 것보다 뭔가에 훨씬 더 반응을 보이거든요. 그래서 맞는 아이디어면 '와, 진짜요, 바로 해요!'라고 하고, 틀리면 '그건 좀 아닌데, 이렇게 해보자' 하면서 다른 방향으로 이끌어줘요.
text_zh: 我觉得吧，就算是个完全错误的想法，你把它抛出来也比什么都不说要强得多，因为大家更容易对一个具体的想法产生反应，而不是对着空气讨论。如果这个想法是对的，他们就会说"哇，太对了，我们就这么干！"如果想法有问题，那他们也会指出来，然后把你往正确的方向引。
text_es: Mi punto de vista es que lanzar una idea, aunque esté completamente equivocada, es un catalizador mucho mejor para llegar a una buena solución, porque la gente tiende más a reaccionar ante una idea que ante el vacío. O sea, si es la idea correcta, van a decir "¡Perfecto, sí, hagámoslo!" Y si está mal, pues te van a orientar hacia otra dirección.
context: Lenny continues asking about developing conviction, particularly for younger PMs who might doubt their opinions compared to more experienced colleagues. Mihika explains her philosophy on sharing ideas and building conviction. She argues that presenting even an imperfect idea is better than presenting nothing, because it gives people something concrete to respond to - either with enthusiasm if it's right, or with constructive redirection if it needs improvement, leading to better outcomes than starting from zero.
vocabulary_highlights: much better catalyst, take you in a different direction
topics: Product Management, Decision Making, Communication Skills

speaker: Mihika Kapoor
speaker_expertise: Product Management, Product Strategy, Product Design
text: Nothing should ever perceive as being out of bounds. My take is that your scope is the world, and to the extent that you can figure out does the idea that you're passionate about fall within your company, versus fall outside of your company, that should guide the next steps in your career.
text_ko: 어떤 것도 경계 밖이라고 느껴져서는 안 돼요. 제 생각에는 여러분의 활동 범위(스코프)는 세상 전체이고, 본인이 진짜 열정을 느끼는 아이디어가 회사 안에서 실현 가능한지, 아니면 회사 밖에서 더 잘 맞는지 가늠해 보는 것이 다음 커리어 방향을 정하는 기준이 돼야 해요.
text_zh: 没有什么东西应该被认为是碰不得的。我的看法是，你的眼界应该放眼全世界，关键是要搞清楚你真正有激情的那个想法，到底是在你现在公司的范围内，还是在公司外面，这个判断应该指导你职业生涯的下一步怎么走。
text_es: Nada debería verse como algo fuera de límites. Mi punto de vista es que tu alcance es el mundo entero, y en la medida en que puedas determinar si esa idea que te apasiona encaja dentro de tu empresa o queda fuera de ella, eso debería marcar los próximos pasos en tu carrera profesional.
context: Lenny asks for advice for people who don't feel passionate about what they're currently working on at their companies. Mihika challenges the common assumption that your scope as a PM is limited to your current project or role. She encourages taking a much broader view - considering the entire company vision, understanding users deeply, and thinking about whether there's anything in that broader space that excites you. She emphasizes that your potential impact and area of influence should be viewed as unlimited rather than constrained by current assignments.
vocabulary_highlights: out of bounds, your scope is the world, to the extent that
topics: Career Development, Product Management, Strategy & Planning

speaker: Mike Krieger
text: I had this notion coming in like, 'Yes, these models are great, but are they able to have an independent opinion?' And it's actually really flipped for me only in the last month. My go-to product strategy partner is Claude. And it has been basically for that full year where I'll write an initial strategy, I'll share it with Claude basically, and I'll have it, look at it.
text_ko: 처음엔 '이 모델들(models)은 훌륭한데, 독립적인 의견을 가질 수 있을까?'라고 생각했어요. 그런데 그 생각은 사실 지난 한 달 사이에 완전히 바뀌었어요. 요즘은 제품 전략(product strategy) 파트너로 Claude를 가장 자주 활용해요. 지난 1년 동안 거의 계속 그랬는데, 제가 초안 전략을 쓰면 Claude에게 공유해서 봐달라고 하고요.
text_zh: 我一开始的想法是，"这些模型确实很棒，但它们能有独立的见解吗？" 但就在上个月，我的想法彻底转变了。现在Claude就是我的首选产品策略伙伴。基本上这整整一年来，我都是这么做的——先写个初步策略方案，然后分享给Claude，让它帮我看看。
text_es: Tenía esta idea al principio de que "sí, estos modelos están geniales, pero ¿realmente pueden tener una opinión independiente?" Y la verdad es que eso me cambió completamente solo en el último mes. Mi compañero de estrategia de producto de cabecera es Claude. Y básicamente ha sido así durante todo este año donde escribo una estrategia inicial, se la comparto básicamente a Claude, y lo pongo a revisarla.
context: Lenny asks Mike what he's changed his mind about regarding AI capabilities since joining Anthropic. Mike explains how he initially doubted whether AI models could provide independent, creative opinions rather than just following instructions. He describes using Claude as his primary thought partner for product strategy development, where he writes strategies and asks Claude to review and critique them.
vocabulary_highlights: flipped for me, go-to product strategy partner, notion coming in
topics: Product Management, Strategy & Planning, Decision Making

speaker: Mike Krieger
text: The team that works in the most futuristic way is the Claude Code team. They're using Claude Code to build Claude Code in a very self-improving kind of way. We really rapidly became bottlenecked on other things like our merge queue. We had to completely re-architect it because so much more code was being written and so many more pull requests were being submitted.
text_ko: 가장 미래지향적으로 일하는 팀은 Claude Code 팀이에요. 그들은 Claude Code를 이용해 Claude Code를 만들고 있는데, 스스로 계속 개선되는 방식으로 운영하고 있어요. 코드가 훨씬 더 많이 작성되고 풀 리퀘스트(pull requests)가 훨씬 더 많이 올라오다 보니 병합 대기열(merge queue) 같은 다른 부분에서 금세 병목이 생겼어요. 그래서 아키텍처를 아예 완전히 다시 설계해야 했어요.
text_zh: Claude Code团队的工作方式最有未来感。他们用Claude Code来开发Claude Code，这种自我改进的方式特别厉害。我们很快就发现瓶颈出现在其他地方，比如合并队列(merge queue)。因为代码写得太多了，提交的拉取请求(pull request)也特别多，我们不得不把整个架构重新设计一遍。
text_es: El equipo que trabaja de la manera más futurista es el equipo de Claude Code. Están usando Claude Code para construir Claude Code de una forma que se automejora constantemente. Muy rápido nos topamos con cuellos de botella (bottlenecks) en otras cosas como nuestra cola de fusión (merge queue). Tuvimos que rediseñar completamente la arquitectura porque se estaba escribiendo muchísimo más código y se estaban enviando muchas más pull requests.
context: Lenny discusses how 90% of Anthropic's code is now written by AI. Mike explains that the Claude Code team represents the most advanced way of working, where they use their own AI coding tool to build and improve itself. This created unexpected infrastructure challenges as the volume of code generation overwhelmed their existing systems for managing code changes.
vocabulary_highlights: self-improving kind of way, rapidly became bottlenecked, re-architect

speaker: Mike Krieger
text: I think there's room for several generationally important companies to be built in AI right now. How do we figure out what we want to be when we grow up versus what we currently aren't or wish that we were or see other players in the space being?
text_ko: 저는 지금 인공지능(AI) 분야에서 세대를 규정할 만한 중요한 회사들이 여러 개 나올 수 있다고 생각해요. 그런데 우리가 커서 어떤 회사가 되고 싶은지와, 현재 우리가 그렇지 못한 점이나 우리가 바라는 모습인지, 아니면 단지 같은 분야의 다른 플레이어들(players)을 보고 있는 건지—이걸 어떻게 구분해요?
text_zh: 我觉得现在AI这个赛道里，完全有空间诞生好几家具有时代意义的公司。关键是我们得想清楚，等我们真正做大了想成为什么样的公司，而不是纠结于我们现在还不是什么、或者羡慕别人在做什么。
text_es: Creo que hay espacio para crear varias empresas generacionalmente importantes en IA ahora mismo. ¿Cómo definimos qué queremos ser cuando maduremos como empresa versus lo que no somos ahora o lo que quisiéramos ser o lo que vemos que están haciendo otros jugadores en el sector?
context: Lenny asks about competing with ChatGPT's consumer mindshare dominance. Mike discusses the strategic challenge of positioning Anthropic in the competitive AI landscape. He emphasizes that multiple significant AI companies can coexist, and the key is focusing on authentic strengths rather than copying competitors' approaches.
vocabulary_highlights: generationally important companies, what we want to be when we grow up, players in the space
topics: Strategy & Planning, Starting a Company, Decision Making

speaker: Mike Krieger
text: I think the role of engineering has changed a lot, but the suite of people that come together to produce a product hasn't yet. And I think for the worst in a lot of ways because I think we're still holding on some assumptions. What I've learned though is the process of knowing what to ask the AI, how to compose the question, how to even think about structuring a change between the backend and the front end. Those are still very difficult and specialized skills and they still require the engineer to think about it.
text_ko: 엔지니어링의 역할은 많이 달라졌다고 생각해요. 그런데 제품을 만들기 위해 모인 사람들의 구성은 아직 바뀌지 않았고, 여러 면에서 오히려 그게 안 좋은 쪽이라고 봐요. 아직도 몇 가지 가정에 매달리고 있기 때문이에요. 제가 배운 건 인공지능(AI)에게 무엇을 물어봐야 하는지, 질문을 어떻게 구성해야 하는지, 백엔드(backend)와 프론트엔드(front end) 사이의 변경을 어떻게 구조화해서 생각해야 하는지 같은 과정들은 여전히 어렵고 전문적인 기술이라는 점이에요. 그래서 결국 엔지니어가 그것들을 직접 고민해야 해요.
text_zh: 我觉得工程师这个角色变化挺大的，但是做产品的那帮人基本没怎么变。而且很多方面我觉得是变差了，因为我们还是抱着一些老想法不放。不过我学到的是，怎么问AI问题，怎么组织问题，甚至怎么考虑后端和前端之间的结构调整，这些还是很难的专业技能，还是需要工程师去动脑子思考的。
text_es: Creo que el rol de la ingeniería ha cambiado un montón, pero el equipo de gente que se junta para sacar un producto todavía no. Y pienso que en muchos aspectos para mal, porque seguimos aferrándonos a ciertas ideas preconcebidas. Pero lo que he aprendido es que el proceso de saber qué preguntarle a la IA, cómo plantear la pregunta, cómo incluso pensar en estructurar un cambio entre el backend y el frontend... esas siguen siendo habilidades muy difíciles y especializadas, y todavía requieren que el ingeniero lo piense bien.
context: Lenny asks how product development changes when 90% of code is written by AI. Mike explains that while engineering roles have transformed significantly, the overall team structure hasn't adapted accordingly. He emphasizes that even with AI writing most code, engineers still need sophisticated skills to properly structure requests and guide the AI effectively.
vocabulary_highlights: suite of people, holding on some assumptions, compose the question

speaker: Mike Krieger
text: At this point, I would be shocked if it wasn't 95% plus. What's been cool is so nitty-gritty stuff, Claude Code is written in TypeScript. It's actually our largest TypeScript project. Most of the rest of Anthropic is written in Python, some Go, some Rust now, but we're not like a TypeScript shop.
text_ko: 지금 이 상황에서 95% 이상이 아닐 거라면 정말 놀랄 것 같아요. 흥미로운 건, Claude Code가 TypeScript로 작성됐다는 거예요. 사실, 이게 우리 최대의 TypeScript 프로젝트예요. 나머지 Anthropic은 대부분 Python으로 작성됐고, 일부는 Go, 일부는 Rust로 되어 있지만, 우리는 TypeScript 전문 회사는 아니에요.
text_zh: 到这个程度，如果不是95%以上我反而会觉得奇怪。有意思的是一些很细节的东西，Claude Code是用TypeScript写的，其实这是我们最大的TypeScript项目。Anthropic其他大部分代码都是用Python写的，也有一些Go，现在还有一些Rust，但我们并不是专门做TypeScript的公司。
text_es: En este punto, me sorprendería mucho si no fuera 95% o más. Lo que ha estado genial es que son cosas muy específicas, muy detalladas. Claude Code está escrito en TypeScript. De hecho, es nuestro proyecto más grande en TypeScript. La mayoría del resto de Anthropic está escrito en Python, algo de Go, algo de Rust ahora, pero no somos como una empresa que se dedique principalmente a TypeScript.
context: Lenny asks what percentage of Claude Code (Anthropic's coding tool) is written by Claude Code itself. Mike estimates it's over 95% and explains how this self-improving approach has enabled developers to contribute to projects in programming languages they don't know, breaking down traditional barriers to entry.
vocabulary_highlights: nitty-gritty stuff, TypeScript shop

speaker: Mike Krieger
text: Our headwinds were a couple. One of them was just mobile websites have really taken a turn. I don't blame any individuals for this. I think it's the market dynamics of it, but we put so much time or designers, sky Gunner Gray who's phenomenal that for Perplexity now, the app experience I was so proud of, but when you click through it was like the pressures on these mobile sites and these mobile publishers would be like, 'Sign up for our newsletter. Here's a full screen video ad.'
text_ko: 우리가 겪은 역풍(headwinds)이 몇 가지 있었어요. 그중 하나는 모바일 사이트(mobile sites) 쪽이 큰 변화를 겪었다는 거예요. 특정 개인을 탓하진 않아요. 이건 시장의 역학(market dynamics) 때문이라고 생각해요. 저희는 디자이너들, 특히 Sky Gunner Gray 같은 훌륭한 분들과 많은 시간을 들여 퍼플렉시티(Perplexity)의 앱 경험(app experience)을 정말 자랑스럽게 만들었는데, 막상 클릭해서 들어가 보면 모바일 사이트들과 모바일 퍼블리셔들(mobile publishers)이 '뉴스레터(newsletter) 구독하세요. 전체화면 동영상 광고(full-screen video ad)입니다.' 이런 식으로 압박이 심하더라고요.
text_zh: 我们遇到的阻力主要有两个。其中一个就是移动网站真的变得很糟糕。我不怪任何个人，我觉得这是市场环境造成的。但我们在这上面投入了太多时间，还有我们的设计师，像Sky Gunner Gray这样超棒的人才，现在为Perplexity做的应用体验我真的很自豪。但问题是当你点击进去的时候，这些移动网站和移动发布商面临的压力太大了，它们就会弹出"订阅我们的通讯"，然后是全屏视频广告。
text_es: Nuestros obstáculos fueron un par de cosas. Uno de ellos fue simplemente que los sitios web móviles han tomado un rumbo bastante malo. No culpo a ninguna persona en particular por esto. Creo que son las dinámicas del mercado, pero invertimos tanto tiempo con nuestros diseñadores, como Gunner Gray que es fenomenal y que ahora trabaja para Perplexity. La experiencia de la app me tenía súper orgulloso, pero cuando hacías clic era como que las presiones sobre estos sitios móviles y estos publishers móviles los hacía decir: "Suscríbete a nuestro newsletter. Aquí tienes un anuncio de video en pantalla completa."
context: Lenny asks why Mike shut down Artifact, his news app startup. Mike explains the challenges they faced, particularly how the deteriorating mobile web experience hurt user engagement. Despite creating a beautiful in-app experience, users would encounter intrusive ads and popups when clicking through to publisher websites.
vocabulary_highlights: headwinds, taken a turn, click through
topics: Starting a Company, Decision Making, Strategy & Planning

speaker: Mike Krieger
text: How do we help people get work done? How do we let people delegate hours of work to Claude? And maybe there's fewer direct consumer applications on day one. I think they'll come, but I don't think that spending all of our time focused on that is the right approach either. And so I came in, everybody expected me to just go super, super hard on consumer and make that the thing and again, would make the other mistake.
text_ko: 사람들이 업무를 해내도록 어떻게 도울까요? 사람들이 몇 시간치 작업을 Claude에게 맡길 수 있게 하려면 어떻게 해야 할까요? 아마도 첫날에는 직접 소비자용 애플리케이션(consumer applications)이 많지 않을 거예요. 나오긴 하겠지만, 그쪽에만 우리 시간을 전부 쏟는 건 옳은 접근법이 아니라고 생각해요. 그래서 제가 합류했을 때 모두들 제가 소비자 쪽에 완전히 몰두해서 그걸 메인으로 만들 거라고 기대했는데, 그렇게 했으면 또 다른 실수를 했을 거예요.
text_zh: 我们怎么帮助人们把工作做好？怎么让人们把几个小时的工作量交给Claude来处理？可能在一开始，直接面向消费者的应用会少一些。我觉得这些应用肯定会有的，但是把所有时间都花在这上面，我觉得也不太对。所以我进来之后，大家都以为我会狠抓消费者市场，把这个当重点，但那样的话又会犯另一个错误。
text_es: ¿Cómo ayudamos a la gente a que haga su trabajo? ¿Cómo logramos que puedan delegarle horas de trabajo a Claude? Y tal vez no haya tantas aplicaciones directas para el consumidor desde el primer día. Creo que van a llegar, pero tampoco pienso que enfocarnos únicamente en eso sea la estrategia correcta. Entonces cuando llegué, todos esperaban que me fuera súper fuerte en el tema de consumidor y que lo hiciera mi prioridad, pero otra vez, eso sería cometer el mismo error.
context: Lenny asks about Anthropic's strategy given ChatGPT's consumer dominance. Mike explains Anthropic's focus on helping people accomplish meaningful work rather than chasing immediate consumer market share. He describes deliberately avoiding the expected approach of prioritizing consumer applications in favor of building strong foundations with developers and business users.
vocabulary_highlights: delegate hours of work, go super, super hard on, make the other mistake
topics: Strategy & Planning, Product Management, Decision Making

speaker: Mike Maples, Jr.
text: The three are inflections, insights and then the founder future fit. Business is never a fair fight. What inflections let the founder do is wage asymmetric warfare on the present.
text_ko: 세 가지는 변곡점(inflections), 인사이트(insights), 그리고 창업자의 미래 적합성(founder future fit)이에요. 사업은 결코 공정한 싸움이 아니에요. 변곡점은 창업자가 현재를 상대로 비대칭 전쟁(asymmetric warfare)을 벌일 수 있게 해줘요.
text_zh: 主要是三个方面：拐点、洞察力，还有创始人未来适配度(founder future fit)。商场如战场，从来就不是公平竞争。拐点(inflections)能让创始人做的就是对现状发起不对称战争(asymmetric warfare)。
text_es: Los tres elementos son las inflexiones, los insights y después el ajuste futuro del fundador (founder future fit). Los negocios nunca son una pelea justa. Lo que las inflexiones le permiten hacer al fundador es librar una guerra asimétrica contra el presente.
context: Lenny asks Mike about the three key elements he's discovered that characterize most breakthrough startup ideas. Mike explains his framework for understanding what separates successful startups from those that fail. He emphasizes that startups can't win by playing by the same rules as established companies - they need to leverage different types of power to create unfair advantages.
vocabulary_highlights: wage asymmetric warfare

speaker: Mike Maples, Jr.
text: The way inventions happen is people get their hands dirty, being awake to the possibility that secrets are there. If you're living in the future and you notice what's missing, your intuition about what to build is far more likely to be right.
text_ko: 발명은 보통 사람들이 직접 뛰어들어 몸으로 부딪치고, 어딘가 비밀이 숨어 있을지도 모른다는 가능성에 깨어 있을 때 일어나요. 미래에 살고 있다고 생각하면서 지금 무엇이 없는지 눈치채면, 무엇을 만들어야 할지에 대한 여러분의 직감이 훨씬 더 옳을 가능성이 커요.
text_zh: 发明创造就是要撸起袖子干实事，要时刻保持敏锐，因为机会就藏在那里。如果你能超前思考，发现市场的空白点，那你对该做什么产品的直觉基本不会错。
text_es: La forma en que surgen los inventos es que la gente se arremanga y se pone a trabajar, manteniéndose alerta a la posibilidad de que ahí hay secretos por descubrir. Si estás viviendo en el futuro y te das cuenta de lo que falta, tu intuición sobre qué construir tiene muchas más probabilidades de estar en lo correcto.
context: Lenny references Mike's concept of 'secrets' - insights that founders discover through hands-on exploration. Mike explains that breakthrough inventions don't come from theoretical thinking but from actively experimenting with new technologies and being alert to unexpected discoveries. He argues that founders who immerse themselves in emerging trends are better positioned to identify what products need to be built.
vocabulary_highlights: get their hands dirty, being awake to the possibility

speaker: Mike Maples, Jr.
text: So startup never beats a big company by executing better. The way startups win is because it proposes a radically different future. Disorients the incumbent and chaotically moves people to that different future.
text_ko: 스타트업(startup)은 단지 실행을 더 잘한다고 해서 대기업(big company)을 이기지 않아요. 스타트업이 이기는 건 근본적으로 다른 미래를 제안하기 때문이에요. 그 제안은 기존 기업(incumbent)을 혼란에 빠뜨리고, 사람들을 혼란스럽게 그 새로운 미래로 끌어가요.
text_zh: 所以说，创业公司从来不是靠执行力更强来打败大公司的。创业公司获胜的方式是提出一个完全不同的未来愿景，让那些老牌公司(incumbent)摸不着头脑，然后把大家都带到那个全新的未来里去。
text_es: Entonces las startups nunca le ganan a una gran empresa por ejecutar mejor. La forma en que las startups triunfan es porque proponen un futuro radicalmente distinto. Desorienta a la empresa establecida y mueve a la gente de manera caótica hacia ese futuro diferente.
context: Mike explains his core thesis about how startups can successfully compete against large, established companies. He uses the David and Goliath metaphor, where David (the startup) can't win through conventional strength but must use unconventional weapons. Mike argues that startups win not by doing things better, but by completely changing the rules of the game and confusing incumbents.
vocabulary_highlights: disorients the incumbent, chaotically moves people

speaker: Mike Maples, Jr.
text: And I also noticed that all the ones that had seemed to do well didn't necessarily follow the best practices that everybody talked about. I didn't see the Twitter guys doing the business model canvas, for example.
text_ko: 그리고 잘된 것처럼 보였던 사례들을 보니까, 다들 말하는 베스트 프랙티스(best practices)를 꼭 따르진 않더라고요. 예를 들어 트위터 창업자들이 비즈니스 모델 캔버스(business model canvas)를 작성하는 걸 보진 못했어요.
text_zh: 我还发现一个现象，那些做得不错的公司，其实也不见得都按照大家说的那些最佳实践来做。比如说，我就没看到推特那帮人搞什么商业模式画布(business model canvas)。
text_es: Y también me di cuenta de que todos los que parecían estar yendo bien no necesariamente seguían las mejores prácticas de las que todo mundo habla. No vi a los tipos de Twitter haciendo el lienzo del modelo de negocio (business model canvas), por ejemplo.
context: Mike shares his realization that led to writing his book about pattern breakers. After discovering he had forgotten about owning shares in Twitch (which sold for $970 million), he began analyzing his most successful investments. He found that 80% of his biggest returns came from companies that pivoted, and these successful companies often ignored conventional startup advice and best practices.
vocabulary_highlights: best practices, business model canvas

speaker: Mike Maples, Jr.
text: But what we need to understand is there need to be these underlying forces underneath the idea to give it the power to escape the gravitational pull of the present. That's what we want. We want a set of powers that we could observe that make it worth pursuing and make it worth navigating the product to the ultimate place.
text_ko: 핵심은, 그 아이디어가 지금의 중력(gravitational pull of the present)에서 벗어날 수 있게 해줄 밑바탕의 힘들이 있어야 한다는 거예요. 그게 우리가 원하는 거예요. 우리가 관찰할 수 있는 일련의 힘들이 있어서, 그 힘들이 그 아이디어를 추구할 만한 가치가 있게 만들고 제품을 궁극적인 목표까지 이끌어갈 만한 이유가 되어줘야 해요.
text_zh: 但是我们要明白的是，一个想法要想摆脱现状的束缚，背后必须要有一些根本性的驱动力在支撑。这就是我们想要的。我们需要一套能够观察到的力量，让这个想法值得我们去追求，值得我们把产品一步步做到最理想的状态。
text_es: Pero lo que tenemos que entender es que tienen que haber estas fuerzas de fondo que impulsen la idea para darle el poder de escapar de la inercia del presente. Eso es lo que buscamos. Queremos un conjunto de elementos que podamos observar que hagan que valga la pena perseguirlo y que valga la pena llevar el producto hasta donde realmente queremos que llegue.
context: Mike explains why his framework focuses on underlying forces rather than just execution. He introduces the concept that successful startups need powerful foundational elements that can overcome the natural tendency for things to stay the same. These forces give startups the energy needed to break free from existing patterns and create new markets, even if their initial product implementation isn't perfect.
vocabulary_highlights: gravitational pull of the present, underlying forces

speaker: Mike Maples, Jr.
text: Most people don't realize that the thing that's underneath us or the thing that's in our hands or the thing that's in our pocket might have a power that when unleashed could change the future. And it's one of the very special things about founders that are great is they recognize, they notice things that we don't know.
text_ko: 대부분 사람들은 발밑에 있거나 손에 들려 있거나 주머니에 있는 것들이 그 힘을 발휘하면 미래를 바꿀 수 있는 잠재력을 가지고 있다는 걸 잘 몰라요. 그리고 정말 훌륭한 창업자들의 특별한 점 중 하나는 우리가 미처 알아채지 못한 것들을 발견하고 알아보는 능력이 있다는 거예요.
text_zh: 大多数人都没意识到，我们身边的东西，手里拿的东西，或者兜里装的东西，可能蕴含着巨大的能量，一旦释放出来就能改变未来。而那些厉害的创始人特别之处就在于，他们能发现我们看不到的东西，能注意到我们注意不到的点。
text_es: La mayoría de la gente no se da cuenta de que eso que tenemos debajo de nuestros pies, o en nuestras manos, o en el bolsillo, puede tener un poder que si lo liberamos, podría cambiar el futuro. Y es una de las cosas más especiales de los grandes fundadores: que logran reconocer, se fijan en cosas que nosotros ni vemos.
context: Mike discusses how great founders have a unique ability to recognize the potential of new technologies or capabilities that others overlook. He's explaining the concept of inflections - external events that create new possibilities for radical change. Using the wheel as an historical example, he points out that most people miss transformative opportunities that are right in front of them.
vocabulary_highlights: when unleashed, right under our nose

speaker: Mike Maples, Jr.
text: But most of the great startups that I've seen have that attribute to them, and the reason is that a great startup, unlike a conventional company that proposes the future as an extension of the present, so that ... Normal companies forecast, they say, I'm going to look forward from the present and forward project what the future will be. Great founders, pattern breakers back cast, they say, it's a given that the future has to be radically different for me to be a big winner, and so, I'm going to look for radically different futures and work backwards from those radically different futures.
text_ko: 제가 본 대부분의 훌륭한 스타트업(startup)들은 그런 특징을 가지고 있어요. 그 이유는 이래요. 훌륭한 스타트업은 현재를 연장선으로 삼아 미래를 제시하는 전형적인 회사(conventional company)와 달라요. 보통 회사들은 현재에서 출발해 미래를 예측(forecast)하고 그걸 앞으로 투영하지만, 위대한 창업자들(founders) — 즉 패턴을 깨는 사람들(pattern breakers)은 '내가 크게 성공하려면 미래가 근본적으로 달라져야 한다'고 전제하고, 그런 근본적으로 다른 미래를 찾아서 거기서부터 역으로 설계(back cast/backcasting)해요.
text_zh: 但是我见过的那些很牛的创业公司，基本上都有这个特质。原因就在于，优秀的创业公司跟传统公司不一样——传统公司把未来看成是现在的延续，就是说...普通公司做预测的时候，会说"我从现在往前看，推测未来会是什么样"。但是那些厉害的创始人，那些打破常规的人(pattern breakers)，他们是反推的(back cast)。他们会说"要想成为大赢家，未来肯定得跟现在完全不一样，所以我要去寻找那些颠覆性的未来，然后从那个未来往回推"。
text_es: Pero la mayoría de las startups exitosas que he visto tienen esa característica, y la razón es que una gran startup, a diferencia de una empresa convencional que ve el futuro como una extensión del presente... Las empresas normales hacen pronósticos, dicen "voy a mirar hacia adelante desde el presente y proyectar cómo va a ser el futuro". Los grandes fundadores, los que rompen patrones (pattern breakers), hacen lo contrario, dicen "para que yo pueda triunfar en grande, el futuro tiene que ser radicalmente diferente, así que voy a buscar futuros radicalmente diferentes y trabajar hacia atrás desde esos futuros radicalmente diferentes".
context: Mike explains the difference between conventional business thinking and pattern-breaking startup thinking. He's discussing why the best startup ideas are often non-consensus and even disliked by most people initially. He introduces the concept of 'backcasting' - where great founders start with a vision of a radically different future and work backwards to figure out how to get there, rather than extrapolating from current trends.
vocabulary_highlights: back cast, forward project, radically different futures

speaker: Molly Graham
text: Google, when I was there, felt like two PhD students paradise. Facebook felt like 19-year-old hacker's dorm room. 80% of the culture of a company is literally defined by the personality of the founder.
text_ko: 제가 구글에 다닐 때는 마치 박사과정(PhD)생 두 명이 사는 천국 같았어요. 페이스북은 19살 해커(hacker)의 기숙사 방 같은 느낌이었고요. 회사 문화의 80%는 사실 창업자(founder)의 성격에 달려 있어요.
text_zh: 我在谷歌的时候，感觉就像是两个博士生的天堂。脸书呢，感觉就像19岁黑客的宿舍一样。说白了，一个公司80%的企业文化都是创始人的性格决定的。
text_es: Google, cuando estuve ahí, se sentía como el paraíso de dos estudiantes de doctorado. Facebook parecía el cuarto de residencia de un hacker de 19 años. El 80% de la cultura de una empresa literalmente se define por la personalidad del fundador.
context: Lenny asks Molly about her experience working with high-performing founders and CEOs at major tech companies. Molly is explaining how the founder's personality shapes company culture, drawing from her experience at both Google and Facebook. She describes how Google felt academic and idea-focused like a university environment, while Facebook had the scrappy, ship-fast energy of a college hacker's workspace, directly reflecting Mark Zuckerberg's personality and approach.
vocabulary_highlights: two PhD students paradise, 19-year-old hacker's dorm room, literally defined by

speaker: Molly Graham
text: So Chamath, when he pitched me on this job, actually drew me a picture on a whiteboard. He said, the way a lot of people do careers is a set of stairs. Just walk up the stairs and you'll get promoted every two years. But that is boring. The much more fun careers are like jumping off cliffs and you do fall, but then you climb out way beyond where the stairs could ever get you.
text_ko: 그래서 Chamath가 이 일을 제안할 때 화이트보드에 직접 그림을 그려 보여줬어요. 많은 사람들이 커리어를 계단처럼 생각해서 계단을 따라 걷기만 하면 2년마다 승진한다고들 하는데, 그건 지루하대요. 훨씬 더 재미있는 커리어는 절벽에서 뛰어내리는 것과 같아서, 뛰어내리면 분명히 떨어지지만 다시 기어올라가 보면 계단으로는 절대 닿을 수 없는 훨씬 더 높은 곳에 올라가게 된다고 했어요.
text_zh: 所以Chamath当时跟我推销这个工作的时候，在白板上给我画了个图。他说，很多人做职业规划就像爬楼梯一样，按部就班地往上走，每两年升个职。但这样太没意思了。真正有趣的职业发展应该像跳悬崖一样，你确实会摔下去，但是爬起来之后你会发现自己到了一个爬楼梯永远到不了的高度。
text_es: Entonces Chamath, cuando me propuso este trabajo, me dibujó algo en la pizarra. Me dijo: "La forma en que mucha gente maneja su carrera profesional es como una escalera. Solo subes escalón por escalón y te ascienden cada dos años. Pero eso es aburridísimo. Las carreras realmente emocionantes son como saltar de un acantilado - sí, te caes, pero después sales adelante y llegas mucho más lejos de lo que cualquier escalera te podría llevar."
context: Lenny asks about Molly's J-curve versus stairs career framework that helped Sarah Caldwell at OpenAI. Molly is telling the story of how Chamath Palihapitiya at Facebook recruited her from HR to work on mobile, explaining his philosophy on career growth. The J-curve represents taking risky career moves that initially feel like falling but eventually lead to much higher achievements than traditional step-by-step promotions.
vocabulary_highlights: pitched me on, set of stairs, jumping off cliffs, climb out way beyond

speaker: Molly Graham
text: Your only goal as a manager, if you do nothing else, is clear roles and clear expectations. That's it. Because honestly, I've taken over a lot of teams in my life and almost always I show up and it turns out that no one knows what their job is and no one knows what success looks like.
text_ko: 관리자라면 다른 걸 아무것도 못 하더라도 해야 할 유일한 목표는 역할을 분명히 하고 기대치를 명확히 하는 거예요. 그게 전부예요. 솔직히 지금까지 많은 팀을 맡아봤는데, 거의 항상 제가 들어가 보면 아무도 자기 일이 뭔지 모르고 성공이 어떤 모습인지도 모르는 경우가 많더라고요.
text_zh: 作为管理者，就算你什么都不做，也得把这两件事搞清楚：角色要明确，期望要清晰。就这么简单。说实话，我接手过很多团队，几乎每次去了都发现，大家根本不知道自己到底该干什么，也不知道怎么样才算做得好。
text_es: Tu único objetivo como manager, si no haces nada más, es tener roles claros y expectativas claras. Ya está. Porque la verdad es que he tomado el mando de muchos equipos en mi vida y casi siempre llego y resulta que nadie sabe cuál es su chamba y nadie sabe cómo se ve el éxito.
context: Lenny asks about Molly's Waterline Model, a framework for diagnosing team problems that she learned from leading wilderness expeditions. The model suggests that 80% of team issues stem from structural problems rather than people problems, and you should 'snorkel before you scuba' - meaning address surface-level structural issues before diving into interpersonal problems. Molly is emphasizing that the most fundamental structural issue is usually unclear roles and expectations.
vocabulary_highlights: if you do nothing else, taken over a lot of teams, turns out that, what success looks like

speaker: Molly Graham
text: No company needs more than three company goals and the point of company goals is to help people know what the most important things are to success. So, Facebook basically had three goals for the entire time I was there, it was five years. So, the three goals were this, there was growth which was measured as monthly active users, that was the externally reported number eventually, MAUs. The second goal was engagement meaning how often do people come back and use the site and the third was revenue.
text_ko: 어떤 회사든 회사 목표는 세 가지를 넘길 필요가 없고, 목표의 목적은 사람들이 성공에 가장 중요한 게 무엇인지 알 수 있게 하는 거예요. 제가 거기 있는 동안(5년간) 페이스북은 기본적으로 세 가지 목표만 있었어요. 첫째는 성장(월간 활성 사용자, monthly active users — MAUs로 측정했고, 결국 외부에 보고되는 숫자였어요). 둘째는 참여도(engagement), 즉 사람들이 얼마나 자주 돌아와서 사이트를 사용하는지에 관한 거예요. 셋째는 수익(revenue)이었어요.
text_zh: 其实公司的目标不需要太多，三个就够了，设定公司目标就是为了让大家都清楚什么是最重要的。像Facebook吧，我在那儿待了五年，基本上就是这三个目标。第一个是增长，用月活用户(monthly active users)来衡量，也就是后来对外公布的MAU数据。第二个是用户粘性(engagement)，就是看用户多久回来用一次我们的产品。第三个就是营收。
text_es: Ninguna empresa necesita más de tres objetivos corporativos, y el punto de tener objetivos es ayudar a la gente a saber cuáles son las cosas más importantes para el éxito. Facebook básicamente tuvo tres objetivos durante todo el tiempo que estuve ahí, fueron cinco años. Los tres objetivos eran estos: primero, crecimiento, que se medía como usuarios activos mensuales, ese era el número que reportábamos públicamente al final, los MAUs. El segundo objetivo era engagement, o sea, qué tan seguido regresa la gente a usar la plataforma, y el tercero era ingresos.
context: Lenny asks Molly about her six rules for creating clear goals and building alignment on teams. Molly is explaining her first rule that companies should have no more than three goals, using Facebook as an example. She's describing how Facebook maintained the same three simple goals - growth (monthly active users), engagement (user retention), and revenue - throughout her five-year tenure there, demonstrating how this clarity helped everyone understand priorities.
vocabulary_highlights: no more than three, the entire time I was there, externally reported number, how often do people come back

speaker: Molly Graham
text: And there's this incredible set of emotions that come territorialistic, paired with excitement. Fear paired with joy. But eventually you pass the house off and then you go work on neighborhoods and you're sort of like, okay, dog parks, I'm good at dog parks. I got this. And then again, you get to the like, I'm great. I was put on earth to build neighborhoods.
text_ko: 그리고 정말 묘한 감정들이 몰려와요 — 영역적 감정(territorialistic)이 들면서도 신나고, 두려움이 기쁨과 섞이기도 해요. 그런데 결국엔 그 집을 넘겨주고 동네 일로 넘어가면, "도그파크(dog parks)는 제가 잘해요. 이건 제가 맡을게요" 하며 자신감이 붙고, 어느 순간 "아, 난 진짜 동네를 만드는 사람으로 이 세상에 태어났나 봐요"라는 생각까지 들어요.
text_zh: 这里面有一套特别复杂的情绪，既有地盘意识，又很兴奋。既害怕又开心。但最终你把房子交出去了，然后开始做整个社区，你就会想，好吧，狗公园这块我拿手，我能搞定。然后你又开始觉得，我真的很厉害，我就是为了建社区而生的。
text_es: Y hay esta mezcla increíble de emociones que te vuelven territorial, pero también te emocionan. Miedo mezclado con alegría. Pero al final entregas la casa y te vas a trabajar en barrios enteros y es como que dices, okay, parques para perros, se me dan bien los parques para perros. Lo tengo controlado. Y otra vez llegas al punto de pensar, soy genial en esto. Nací para construir barrios.
context: Lenny asks about Molly's famous 'giving away your Legos' framework for career growth in scaling companies. Molly uses a metaphor where work responsibilities are like building with Legos - you start building houses, get good at it, but then need to pass that work to someone else and move on to building dog parks and neighborhoods as the company scales. She's describing the complex emotions people feel when they have to give up work they've mastered and enjoyed.
vocabulary_highlights: territorialistic, paired with excitement, I got this, I was put on earth to

speaker: Molly Graham
text: Growing more than 100% every year is a bad idea. The happiest growth rate is 50%, 100% is manageable. Anything more than doubling and you are signing yourself up for a world of pain. And I have seen this over and over and over again.
text_ko: 매년 100% 이상 성장하는 건 좋은 생각이 아니에요. 가장 편한 성장률은 50%고, 100%는 감당할 만해요. 두 배 이상 성장하면 온갖 고생을 자초하게 돼요. 저는 이걸 정말 수도 없이 여러 번 봐왔어요.
text_zh: 每年增长超过100%其实不是什么好事。最理想的增长率是50%，100%还能应付得来。但要是超过翻倍的话，你就等着受罪吧。这种情况我见得太多了，一个接一个都是这样。
text_es: Crecer más del 100% cada año es mala idea. El ritmo de crecimiento más cómodo es 50%, el 100% todavía se puede manejar. Pero si creces más del doble, te estás metiendo en un lío tremendo. Y esto lo he visto una y otra vez.
context: Lenny asks about lessons Molly learned from high-performing leaders like Mark Zuckerberg and Cheryl Sandberg. Molly is sharing advice from Cheryl Sandberg about sustainable company growth rates in terms of headcount. She's explaining that while companies often want to triple their team size in a year, this creates chaos, duplication of roles, and inefficiency - it's better to grow more slowly and hire for quality rather than panic hiring.
vocabulary_highlights: happiest growth rate, signing yourself up for, world of pain, over and over and over again

speaker: Molly Graham
text: The most valuable thing that happens as you fall is learning. And even on the other side of failure, you've learned a shit ton. I always say, the most important thing to do in the falling phase and the risk taking land is to learn to embrace being a professional idiot.
text_ko: 넘어질 때 가장 가치 있는 건 배움이에요. 그리고 실패를 겪은 뒤에도 배운 게 엄청 많아요. 저는 항상 말해요: 넘어지는 단계(falling phase)와 리스크를 감수하는 영역(risk-taking land)에서는 '프로페셔널 이디엇(professional idiot)'이 되는 걸 기꺼이 받아들이는 법을 배우는 게 가장 중요하다고요.
text_zh: 跌倒过程中最宝贵的就是学到东西。就算失败了，你也学到了一大堆。我总说，在跌倒和冒险这个阶段，最重要的就是要学会接受自己是个"专业菜鸟"。
text_es: Lo más valioso que pasa cuando te caes es el aprendizaje. Y aún del otro lado del fracaso, has aprendido un chingo. Siempre digo que lo más importante en la fase de caída y en el mundo de tomar riesgos es aprender a aceptar ser un idiota profesional.
context: Lenny asks about advice for the difficult 'falling' period of the J-curve when someone takes on a challenging new role. The J-curve represents career moves where you initially struggle and feel like you're falling before eventually climbing to new heights. Molly is explaining that the key to surviving and thriving during this difficult period is to focus on learning everything you can, even if you feel incompetent, because that learning is what ultimately leads to success.
vocabulary_highlights: shit ton, falling phase, risk taking land, professional idiot

speaker: Nabeel S. Qureshi
speaker_expertise: AI/ML Products, Data Analytics, B2B SaaS
text: I feel like they screened really hard for a few traits in particular. One is like very independent-minded people who weren't afraid to push back. Two is people with broader intellectual interests.
text_ko: 제 생각에는 몇 가지 특성을 특히 엄격하게 가려 뽑은 것 같아요. 하나는 반박하는 걸 두려워하지 않고 독립적으로 사고하는 사람들이고, 다른 하나는 지적 관심사가 넓은 사람들이에요.
text_zh: 我感觉他们筛人的时候特别看重几个点。第一个就是要那种很有主见的人，敢于据理力争的那种。第二个是要知识面比较广的人。
text_es: Siento que filtraron muy a fondo buscando ciertos tipos de personas en particular. Una cosa era gente muy independiente de pensamiento que no tuviera miedo de dar la contra. Y la otra, personas con intereses intelectuales más amplios.
context: Lenny asks Nabeel to describe what the people are like at Palantir, noting that 30% of PMs who leave Palantir start companies. Nabeel explains that Palantir had very specific hiring criteria that attracted a particular type of talent. He describes how the company deliberately screened for traits that would create effective forward deployed engineers and future founders.
vocabulary_highlights: screened really hard, independent-minded, push back, broader intellectual interests

speaker: Nabeel S. Qureshi
speaker_expertise: AI/ML Products, Data Analytics, B2B SaaS
text: You need something that actually a lot of people are going to go, 'Why are you taking this principle? This seems wrong to me.' So, you need something that people can disagree with.
text_ko: 사람들이 실제로 “왜 이런 원칙을 택하죠? 이건 잘못된 것 같아요”라고 말할 정도로 반대할 만한 게 필요해요.
text_zh: 你需要找到一个真正会让很多人质疑的原则，让他们觉得"你怎么能这样做？这不对啊。" 所以说，你需要的就是一个有争议的东西，让大家可以有不同看法。
text_es: Necesitas algo con lo que mucha gente vaya a decir: "¿Por qué estás aplicando este principio? A mí me parece que está mal." O sea, necesitas algo que genere debate, que la gente pueda cuestionar.
context: Lenny and Nabeel are discussing how Palantir's distinctive culture attracts specific talent by being polarizing. Nabeel explains the concept of a 'murder board' process at Palantir where team members would critique project plans. He's giving advice about writing effective principles for projects, emphasizing that good principles should be controversial rather than universally agreeable.
vocabulary_highlights: murder board, tear apart your plan

speaker: Nabeel S. Qureshi
speaker_expertise: AI/ML Products, Data Analytics, B2B SaaS
text: You would spend maybe Monday to Thursday and you would actually go into the building where the customer worked and you would work alongside them. You would literally get a desk there and so, that engineer became known as a forward deployed engineer.
text_ko: 보통 월요일부터 목요일까지는 고객이 일하는 건물로 직접 가서 옆에서 같이 일했어요. 말 그대로 그곳에 자리를 배정받아 앉아 일했고, 그래서 그런 엔지니어를 '현장 상주 엔지니어(forward deployed engineer)'라고 불렀어요.
text_zh: 你可能周一到周四都要待在那儿，直接到客户公司的办公楼里去，跟他们一起干活。真的就是在那儿给你安排个工位，所以这种工程师就叫做前置部署工程师(forward deployed engineer)。
text_es: Pasabas digamos de lunes a jueves y literalmente ibas al edificio donde trabajaba el cliente y trabajabas codo a codo con ellos. Te daban un escritorio ahí mismo y así, ese ingeniero se conocía como ingeniero desplegado en campo (forward deployed engineer).
context: Lenny asks about the difference between a Palantir PM and a traditional PM, which leads to Nabeel explaining the forward deployed engineer role. Forward deployed engineers are a unique position that Palantir created where technical staff work directly at customer sites rather than remotely. This role is central to Palantir's business model and success in developing customer-focused solutions.
vocabulary_highlights: forward deployed engineer, sent into the field

speaker: Nabeel S. Qureshi
speaker_expertise: AI/ML Products, Data Analytics, B2B SaaS
text: So, you get four of these, five of these cycles every single week, and you're moving incredibly fast. So 6 weeks in, you've suddenly gotten to, wow, this is really valuable, and somebody's willing to pay you whatever, $20 million for it, and boom.
text_ko: 그러니까 매주 이런 사이클(cycle)을 네다섯 번 돌리면 속도가 엄청 빨라요. 6주쯤 지나면 갑자기 "이거 정말 가치 있네" 하고 누군가가 기꺼이 2천만 달러($20 million)를 지불하겠다고 하고, 그럼 한순간에 일이 확 터져요.
text_zh: 这样一来，你每周能跑四到五个这样的循环，速度快得不得了。所以6周过去，你突然发现，哇，这东西真的很值钱，有人愿意花个2000万美金买你的东西，一下子就成了。
text_es: Entonces, tienes cuatro de estos, cinco de estos ciclos cada semana, y estás avanzando súper rápido. Así que a las 6 semanas, de repente llegas al punto de "guau, esto es realmente valioso", y alguien está dispuesto a pagarte no sé, 20 millones de dólares por eso, y ¡pum!
context: Nabeel is explaining how the forward deployed engineer model creates rapid iteration cycles that benefit both customers and Palantir. He describes the weekly rhythm where engineers work on-site with customers, build solutions, get immediate feedback, and iterate quickly. This fast feedback loop allows them to develop valuable solutions that customers will pay significant amounts for.
vocabulary_highlights: moving incredibly fast, boom

speaker: Nabeel S. Qureshi
speaker_expertise: AI/ML Products, Data Analytics, B2B SaaS
text: I think the error that people make more often than not is they are actually too stuck on their own product vision. That's the mistake I've seen a little bit more actually than the other way around.
text_ko: 사람들이 대체로 저지르는 실수는 자기 제품 비전(product vision)에 너무 집착하는 거라고 생각해요. 제 경험상 반대보다 이쪽 실수를 더 자주 봤어요.
text_zh: 我觉得大家最容易犯的错误其实是太执着于自己的产品愿景了。说实话，我见过的这种情况反而比相反的情况要多一些。
text_es: Creo que el error que comete la mayoría de la gente es que se aferran demasiado a su propia visión del producto. Ese es el error que he visto más a menudo, la verdad, más que lo contrario.
context: Lenny asks about advice for founders on how far to go in solving one customer's specific problem versus building a general platform. Nabeel explains that most founders make the mistake of being too rigid about their original product vision rather than being flexible enough to pivot toward solving the customer's actual biggest problem, even if it's different from what they initially planned.
vocabulary_highlights: stuck on, product vision, the other way around

speaker: Nabeel S. Qureshi
speaker_expertise: AI/ML Products, Data Analytics, B2B SaaS
text: The key things that made our model work well, one, they were actually real engineers who could build product themselves. That's a very big difference. I think a lot of the time companies will say, 'This person's a forward deployed engineer,' but actually they're mostly there to be more of a solutions architect.
text_ko: 우리가 만든 모델이 잘 돌아가게 만든 핵심은, 첫째로 실제로 제품을 스스로 만들어낼 수 있는 진짜 엔지니어들이었다는 거예요. 그건 정말 큰 차이예요. 많은 회사들이 '이 사람은 포워드 디플로이드 엔지니어(forward deployed engineer)다'라고 말하곤 하는데, 실제로는 대부분 솔루션 아키텍트(solutions architect)에 더 가깝더라고요.
text_zh: 我们这个模式能成功，关键在于几点。第一，我们派出去的都是真正的工程师，他们自己就能做产品开发。这个差别可大了。我发现很多公司嘴上说"这是我们的前线工程师(forward deployed engineer)"，但实际上他们主要就是做方案架构师(solutions architect)的活儿。
text_es: Las claves que hicieron que nuestro modelo funcionara bien fueron, primero, que eran ingenieros de verdad que podían desarrollar el producto ellos mismos. Esa es una diferencia enorme. Creo que muchas veces las empresas dicen 'Esta persona es un ingeniero desplegado en campo (forward deployed engineer)', pero en realidad está ahí más bien para hacer de arquitecto de soluciones (solutions architect).
context: Lenny asks what founders should get right if they want to implement a forward deployed engineer model at their own company. Nabeel emphasizes that the most critical element is having engineers who can actually build new products, not just deploy existing ones. Many companies incorrectly use the title for roles that are more like solutions architects or sales engineers.
vocabulary_highlights: real engineers, solutions architect, very big difference

speaker: Nan Yu
speaker_expertise: B2B SaaS, Product Design, Product Management
text: People talk about this as if there were a trade-off because when they think about speed, the thing they over-index on is rushing or being sloppy. What they should be indexing on is being really competent. If you look at people who are at the pinnacle of their craft, you can basically tell how good the output is going to be of their work product by how fast they're going.
text_ko: 사람들은 이걸 마치 트레이드오프(trade-off)인 것처럼 얘기해요. 속도를 생각할 때 사람들이 지나치게 신경 쓰는 건 서두르거나 대충하는 쪽이에요. 대신 진짜로 중점 둬야 할 건 얼마나 유능한가예요. 분야 최고 수준의 사람들을 보면, 그들이 얼마나 빠르게 일하는지만 보고도 산출물(work product)의 퀄리티가 거의 바로 보인다고 할 수 있어요.
text_zh: 大家总觉得这是个取舍问题，因为一提到速度，他们就想到匆忙或者马虎。其实应该关注的是能力水平够不够强。你看那些行业顶尖的人，基本上从他们的工作速度就能看出来最终成果会有多好。
text_es: La gente habla de esto como si fuera una disyuntiva porque cuando piensan en velocidad, lo que más valoran es apurarse o hacer las cosas a las carreras. En lo que deberían enfocarse es en ser realmente competentes. Si te fijas en la gente que está en la cima de su área, básicamente puedes saber qué tan bueno va a ser el resultado de su trabajo por la velocidad con la que trabajan.
context: Lenny asks Nan about his perspective that there's not actually a trade-off between speed and quality in product development, which many people assume to be true. Nan explains that when people think about speed, they mistakenly focus on rushing or being sloppy rather than building expertise and competence. He argues that truly skilled practitioners - whether chefs, programmers, or builders - can deliver high-quality work quickly because their expertise allows them to move rapidly without sacrificing quality.
vocabulary_highlights: over-index on, at the pinnacle of their craft, work product

speaker: Nan Yu
speaker_expertise: B2B SaaS, Product Design, Product Management
text: What it really looks like is you have some rough time budget for how long you think something's going to take. By the time 10% of it has passed, after week one, you have something that works that tests some kind of key hypothesis internally.
text_ko: 실제로는 어떤 일이 얼마나 걸릴지에 대해 대략적인 시간 예산(time budget)을 잡아 놓는 식이에요. 전체 기간의 10%가 지났을 때, 보통 일주일쯤 지나면 내부에서 핵심 가설(key hypothesis)을 검증할 수 있는 작동하는 결과물이 나와 있어요.
text_zh: 实际情况是这样的，你心里大概有个时间预算，估计这事儿要花多长时间。等到过了10%的时间，也就是第一周之后，你就得拿出个能用的东西来，能在内部验证一些关键假设。
text_es: Lo que realmente pasa es que tienes un cálculo más o menos de cuánto tiempo crees que te va a llevar algo. Para cuando haya pasado el 10% de ese tiempo, después de la primera semana, ya tienes algo que funciona y que te permite probar internamente alguna hipótesis clave.
context: Lenny asks Nan to explain what speed actually looks like in practice when building high-quality products quickly. Nan describes Linear's approach to rapid iteration: instead of waiting until a project is halfway done to have something testable, they aim to have a working solution within the first 10% of their allocated time budget. This allows them to validate key assumptions early and avoid pushing deadlines when they discover incorrect assumptions late in the process.
vocabulary_highlights: time budget, key hypothesis

speaker: Nan Yu
speaker_expertise: B2B SaaS, Product Design, Product Management
text: When we examine this problem, we look at, 'Well, what feature requests can we debate and what kind of feature requests do we absolutely have to say no to?' The stuff that we absolutely have to say no to is the exact kind of thing that leads to this bloatedness that makes ICs hate their lives.
text_ko: 이 문제를 살펴볼 때 우리는 '어떤 기능 요청(feature requests)은 논의할 수 있고, 어떤 기능 요청은 꼭 거절해야 할까?'를 따져봐요. 꼭 거절해야 하는 요청들이 바로 IC들(Individual Contributors)이 일하면서 진짜로 고통받게 만드는, 불필요하게 비대해지는(bloatedness) 주범이에요.
text_zh: 我们分析这个问题的时候，会考虑"哪些功能需求我们可以讨论讨论，哪些功能需求我们必须直接拒绝？"那些我们必须直接说不的需求，恰恰就是那种会让产品变得臃肿，让一线员工(IC)痛不欲生的东西。
text_es: Cuando analizamos este problema, nos preguntamos: "Bueno, ¿qué solicitudes de funcionalidades podemos debatir y a cuáles definitivamente tenemos que decir que no?" Precisamente las cosas a las que tenemos que decir no rotundamente son las que llevan a esa sobrecarga (bloatedness) que hace que los colaboradores individuales (ICs) terminen odiando su trabajo.
context: Lenny asks about criticism that Linear will eventually become bloated enterprise software like other tools. Nan explains Linear's systematic approach to avoiding feature bloat by categorizing feature requests into those they can debate versus those they must automatically reject. The requests they always reject are customization features requested by middle managers for reporting purposes, which make individual contributor (IC) workflows worse while providing minimal value to the actual users doing the work.
vocabulary_highlights: bloatedness, ICs hate their lives

speaker: Nan Yu
speaker_expertise: B2B SaaS, Product Design, Product Management
text: My goal is to feel bad in the same way that customers feel bad.
text_ko: 제 목표는 고객들이 느끼는 불편함을 똑같이 느껴보는 거예요.
text_zh: 我的目标就是要和客户感受到一样的痛点。
text_es: Mi objetivo es sentir la misma frustración que sienten nuestros clientes.
context: Lenny mentions that Linear's head of sales is impressed with how Nan asks questions on customer calls and keeps digging until he gets meaningful insights. Nan explains his approach to customer discovery calls, which goes beyond typical analytical frameworks like asking 'five whys.' His goal is to understand and literally experience the same emotional pain points that customers feel, rather than just understanding their functional requirements or goals.
vocabulary_highlights: feel bad

speaker: Nan Yu
speaker_expertise: B2B SaaS, Product Design, Product Management
text: What is the actual emotional valence that is motivating whatever you're telling me? And it takes a little while to get there. You can ask people directly like, 'How do you feel?' And they're not necessarily going to tell you, but if you have a long enough and deep enough conversation with them, you start to level with them.
text_ko: 당신이 저한테 하는 말들을 움직이게 하는 실제 감정적 기조(emotional valence)가 뭔가요? 그걸 알아내려면 시간이 좀 걸려요. 사람들에게 '기분이 어떠세요?'처럼 직접 물어볼 수는 있는데, 다들 바로 말해주진 않아요. 하지만 충분히 길고 깊게 대화를 나누면 상대와 점점 마음을 터놓고 솔직해지기 시작해요.
text_zh: 你跟我说这些话背后真正的情绪动机是什么？这个得慢慢挖掘。你直接问别人"你感觉怎么样？"人家不一定会跟你说实话，但如果你跟他们聊得够久够深入，慢慢地他们就会跟你掏心窝子了。
text_es: ¿Cuál es realmente la carga emocional que está detrás de lo que me estás contando? Y lleva su tiempo llegar ahí. Puedes preguntarle directamente a la gente "¿Cómo te sientes?" pero no necesariamente te van a decir la verdad. Pero si tienes una conversación lo suficientemente larga y profunda con ellos, empiezas a conectar de verdad y ahí es cuando se abren contigo.
context: Nan continues explaining his customer discovery approach, describing how he digs deeper than surface-level goals to understand the emotional motivations behind customer requests. He explains that customers won't directly tell you how they feel when asked, but through extended conversations where you demonstrate empathy and understanding, they begin to open up about the real emotional pain points driving their need for solutions.
vocabulary_highlights: emotional valence, level with them
topics: Product Management, Communication Skills, Coaching & Development

speaker: Nan Yu
speaker_expertise: B2B SaaS, Product Design, Product Management
text: So, we have some rough time budget for how long you think something's going to take, and by the time 10% of it has passed, you have a workable solution. It's not like, 'Oh, at the halfway point, we have something that is maybe a candidate that we can play around with.' It's like, no, no, no. After week one you have something that works that tests some kind of key hypothesis internally so that you can feel like is this thing actually panning out the way we expect it to or did we have some crazy incorrect assumption?
text_ko: 그러니까 우리가 어떤 일에 대해 대략적인 시간 배정(time budget)을 잡아두면, 그중 10%가 지났을 때는 이미 작동하는 해결책(workable solution)이 나와 있어야 해요. 중간 지점에 가서 겨우 '아마 시험해볼 만한 후보가 있겠지' 하는 식은 아니에요. 첫 주가 끝날 무렵에는 내부적으로 어떤 핵심 가설(key hypothesis)을 검증해볼 수 있는, 실제로 돌아가는 무언가가 있어서 이게 우리가 기대한 대로 되는지 아니면 완전히 잘못된 가정을 했는지 확인할 수 있어야 해요.
text_zh: 所以我们会大概估算一下这件事要花多长时间，然后当10%的时间过去后，你就得有个能用的方案了。不是说"哦，到一半的时候，我们可能会有个候选方案可以试试看"。不不不，不是这样的。第一周结束你就得有个能跑起来的东西，能测试一些核心假设，这样你就能感觉到——这事儿到底是不是按我们预期的方向发展，还是说我们一开始就有什么离谱的错误假设？
text_es: Entonces, tenemos como un presupuesto de tiempo aproximado de cuánto creemos que va a tomar algo, y cuando ya pasó el 10% de ese tiempo, ya tienes una solución que funciona. No es como "Ay, ya a la mitad del proyecto tenemos algo que tal vez sea candidato para probar." No, no, no. Después de la primera semana ya tienes algo que jala y que pone a prueba alguna hipótesis clave internamente, para que puedas sentir si esto realmente está saliendo como esperábamos o si teníamos alguna suposición completamente equivocada.
context: Lenny asks for more specifics about what speed looks like in product development. Nan elaborates on Linear's rapid iteration approach, emphasizing that they don't wait until the project is 50% complete to have something testable. Instead, within just the first week (roughly 10% of a month-long project), they have working software that can validate or invalidate their core assumptions, preventing late-stage discoveries that would force deadline pushouts and disappoint other teams.
vocabulary_highlights: workable solution, panning out, crazy incorrect assumption

speaker: Nan Yu
speaker_expertise: B2B SaaS, Product Design, Product Management
text: I think when people talk about being opinionated, it can feel like they're almost saying like, 'Hey, this is arbitrary,' like your opinion and my opinion, they're just too opinions, man. Neither is right or wrong. What we try to do is find where there's actual consensus amongst a lot of different high performing teams, and then we can take those practices and say like, 'Okay, for a team that isn't already practicing this, can we give them a button so that they can start practicing this?'
text_ko: 사람들이 '주관이 뚜렷하다(opinionated)'고 말할 때, 그게 거의 '이건 그냥 임의적이야'라는 식으로 들릴 때가 있어요 — 네 의견이든 내 의견이든 그냥 의견일 뿐이라서 어느 쪽이 옳고 그르다 하긴 어렵다는 뉘앙스요. 우리가 하려는 건 여러 고성과 팀들 사이에서 실제로 합의(consensus)가 있는 지점을 찾아내는 거예요. 그리고 그런 관행을 모아서, 아직 그렇게 하지 않는 팀에게는 '버튼 하나만 누르면 이걸 시작할 수 있게 해줄 수 있을까?' 하고 쉽게 적용해 줄 수 있게 만드는 거죠.
text_zh: 我觉得大家聊到"有主见"这个事儿的时候，感觉就像在说"嘿，这都是随便想的"，你的想法我的想法，就是两个观点嘛，哥们儿，没啥对错之分。我们想做的是找到那些高绩效团队之间真正的共识点，然后把这些做法拿过来说"好，对于还没开始这么干的团队，咱们能不能给他们提供个简单的方法，让他们也能上手试试？"
text_es: Creo que cuando la gente habla de tener opiniones fuertes, puede sonar como si dijeran "oye, esto es totalmente subjetivo", como que tu opinión y la mía son solo eso, dos opiniones, ¿no? Que ninguna está bien o mal. Lo que nosotros tratamos de hacer es encontrar dónde hay consenso real entre muchos equipos de alto rendimiento diferentes, y entonces podemos tomar esas prácticas y decir "bueno, para un equipo que todavía no está haciendo esto, ¿podemos darles una herramienta para que puedan empezar a implementarlo?"
context: Lenny asks about Linear's opinionated approach to product design and whether they have a specific methodology. Nan clarifies that when Linear is 'opinionated,' they're not making arbitrary choices based on personal preferences. Instead, they identify best practices that have consensus among high-performing teams and then build features that make it easy for other teams to adopt these proven workflows, essentially giving teams a button to activate successful practices.
vocabulary_highlights: opinionated, consensus amongst, high performing teams
topics: Product Management, Strategy & Planning, Leadership & Management

speaker: Nancy Duarte
speaker_expertise: User Experience, Marketing Strategy, Leadership Development
text: A lot of people think that the only time you really need to present well is when you have a big stage talk and you make the big investment in the script. The big investment in the contrasting story. I'll tell you a dirty little secret. I can get my husband to do chores for me on the weekends with a real quick, what is, what could be new bliss. So, the ability to just have that contrast as a framework in your brain during a meeting, on a phone call, any moment of influence, like literally it works. It works in any format.
text_ko: 많은 사람들이 진짜로 발표를 잘해야 하는 때는 큰 무대에서 발표할 때 뿐이고, 그때 스크립트(script)에 크게 투자하고 대비되는 이야기(contrasting story)에 공을 들여야 한다고 생각해요. 그런데 제가 하나 비밀을 알려드릴게요. 주말에 남편에게 집안일을 시킬 때도 '지금(what is)은 이렇고, 이렇게 바뀌면 어떨까(what could be)' 같은 아주 짧은 대비만 보여줘도 바로 움직여요. 회의 중이든 전화 통화든, 영향력을 미치는 순간(moment of influence)에 머릿속에 그 대비를 프레임워크(framework)처럼 갖고 있는 능력만 있어도 진짜 효과가 있어요. 어떤 형식(format)에서든 통해요.
text_zh: 很多人觉得只有在大型演讲台上，花大力气准备演讲稿、精心设计对比故事的时候，才需要好好展示。我跟你们说个小秘密吧。我在家里用一个超简单的"现状对比理想状态"的套路，就能让我老公周末帮我干家务。所以说，在开会时、打电话时、任何需要影响别人的时候，脑子里有这种对比的思维框架，真的特别管用。不管什么场合都好使。
text_es: Mucha gente piensa que solo necesitas presentar bien cuando tienes una charla importante en un escenario grande y haces una gran inversión en el guión. La gran inversión en la historia de contraste. Te voy a contar un secretito. Puedo conseguir que mi marido haga las tareas domésticas los fines de semana con un rápido "qué es lo que hay ahora" versus "qué podría ser la nueva felicidad". O sea, tener esa capacidad de contraste como marco mental durante una reunión, en una llamada, en cualquier momento de influencia - literalmente funciona. Funciona en cualquier formato.
context: Lenny asks about when to apply Nancy's story structure methodology to presentations. Nancy explains her 'what is, what could be, new bliss' framework - a simplified version of her three-act story structure where you present the current state, contrast it with an ideal future state, and paint a picture of the benefits. She reveals that this technique works not just for major presentations but for any moment of influence, even convincing her husband to help with household tasks.
vocabulary_highlights: dirty little secret, moment of influence, contrast as a framework

speaker: Nancy Duarte
speaker_expertise: User Experience, Marketing Strategy, Leadership Development
text: Empathy is important to Duarte, everything we do is empathy first. And some of it comes from my own childhood story a little bit. I was raised by a clinically narcissistic mom and narcissist are missing the empathy gene. So, I feel like that void of not having it modeled for me is why I keep clawing at empathy as being important.
text_ko: 공감(empathy)은 Duarte에게 정말 중요해요. 우리가 하는 모든 일은 공감부터 시작해요. 그리고 이건 제 어린 시절 이야기에서 조금 비롯된 면도 있어요. 저는 임상적으로 나르시시즘(narcissism)이 있던 엄마 밑에서 자랐어요. 나르시시스트(narcissist)들은 공감(empathy)이 결여돼 있는 경우가 많아요. 그래서 제게 공감을 보여주는 본보기가 없었던 그 공허함 때문에, 제가 공감(empathy)을 그렇게 중요하게 여기고 계속 붙잡으려고 애쓰는 것 같아요.
text_zh: 同理心对Duarte来说特别重要，我们做任何事都把同理心放在第一位。这跟我小时候的经历也有点关系。我妈妈是临床诊断的自恋型人格(narcissistic personality)，自恋的人天生就缺乏同理心基因。正因为从小没有人给我做这方面的榜样，所以我现在才会一直强调同理心的重要性，一直在这方面努力。
text_es: Para Duarte, la empatía es fundamental, todo lo que hacemos parte de la empatía primero. Y parte de esto viene un poco de mi propia historia de la infancia. Me crié con una mamá clínicamente narcisista y los narcisistas no tienen el gen de la empatía. Entonces, siento que ese vacío de no haber tenido ese ejemplo es por lo que sigo insistiendo tanto en que la empatía es importante.
context: Lenny asks Nancy why empathy is so central to her presentation methodology and what it looks like in practice. Nancy explains that empathy is the foundation of all her work at Duarte, stemming from her personal experience growing up without empathy being modeled for her. She believes this childhood experience drives her focus on making empathy the core of effective communication, especially since many people work for bosses who lack empathy.
vocabulary_highlights: clawing at, missing the empathy gene, void of not having it modeled

speaker: Nancy Duarte
speaker_expertise: User Experience, Marketing Strategy, Leadership Development
text: When I got to really digging into the mentor, I realized it's really the mentor in myths and movies that's the presenter and who really holds the power in the room of a presentation is the audience, the audience gets to make a choice if they accept or reject your idea. So, the balance of power is with them and not you. So, it really is the role of the presenter to be the mentor.
text_ko: 멘토(mentor)에 대해 깊이 파고들어 보니, 신화나 영화에 나오는 멘토가 발표자(presenter)로 여겨지곤 하지만, 실제 발표에서는 진짜 힘을 쥐고 있는 쪽은 청중(audience)더라고요. 청중은 당신의 아이디어를 받아들일지 거부할지 선택할 권한이 있으니까요. 그래서 힘의 균형(balance of power)은 청중 쪽에 있고 발표자 쪽에 있는 게 아니에요. 결국 발표자(presenter)의 역할은 멘토(mentor)가 되는 거예요.
text_zh: 当我深入研究导师这个概念时，我意识到其实在神话故事和电影里，导师才是那个做演示的人。而在演示现场真正掌握主动权的是听众，听众有选择权，他们可以接受你的想法，也可以拒绝。所以主导权其实在他们手里，不在你这儿。因此，演示者真正应该扮演的角色就是导师。
text_es: Cuando me puse a analizar bien el tema del mentor, me di cuenta de que en realidad el mentor de los mitos y las películas es el presentador, y quien realmente tiene el poder en una presentación es la audiencia - ellos son los que deciden si aceptan o rechazan tu idea. O sea, el equilibrio del poder está con ellos, no contigo. Entonces, el rol del presentador es ser el mentor.
context: Nancy is explaining her core philosophy that 'the audience is the hero' of any presentation. She describes how she initially thought the presenter was the hero since they're the central figure on stage, but through studying storytelling archetypes, she realized the presenter should actually play the role of the mentor. The audience holds the real power because they get to choose whether to accept or reject the presenter's ideas, similar to how mentors in myths and movies guide heroes on their journeys.
vocabulary_highlights: digging into, balance of power, role of the presenter

speaker: Nancy Duarte
speaker_expertise: User Experience, Marketing Strategy, Leadership Development
text: So, that rise and fall of hey, here's our current problem, here's a solution, or here's the state of the union. But we imagine it could look like this. There's so many different ways to build that cadence of contrast that's so lovely. I mean it really works. I think the talk came out in 2011 and the amounts of notes and emails of things people have accomplished by changing the structure of their presentation has been really astounding.
text_ko: 그러니까 '지금 우리 문제는 이거고, 해결책은 이거다' 혹은 '현황보고(state of the union)' 식으로 오르내리는 흐름이 있는데, 우리는 이걸 이렇게 보일 수도 있다고 상상해요. 대조의 리듬(cadence of contrast)을 만드는 방법이 정말 다양해요. 정말 멋지고, 효과가 있어요. 그 강연(talk)이 2011년에 나왔는데, 발표 구조를 바꿔서 사람들이 해낸 일들에 대해 받은 메모랑 이메일의 양이 정말 어마어마해요.
text_zh: 所以就是这种起起伏伏的节奏感，比如"嘿，这是我们现在面临的问题，这是解决方案"，或者"这是现状，但我们设想可以是这个样子"。你可以用很多不同的方式来打造这种对比的节奏感，真的特别棒。我是说，这招真的很管用。我记得那个演讲是2011年出来的，从那以后收到的各种留言和邮件，讲他们通过改变演示结构取得的成果，真的让人刮目相看。
text_es: Entonces, esa subida y bajada de "oye, este es nuestro problema actual, aquí tienes una solución", o "este es el estado de las cosas, pero imagínate que pudiera verse así". Hay muchísimas formas diferentes de crear ese ritmo de contrastes que funciona de maravilla. En serio, funciona increíble. Creo que la charla salió en 2011 y la cantidad de notas y emails de cosas que la gente ha logrado simplemente cambiando la estructura de sus presentaciones ha sido impresionante.
context: Nancy is describing her famous presentation structure that creates a visual pattern like 'pumpkin teeth' - alternating between 'what is' (current reality) and 'what could be' (future possibility). She explains how this cadence of contrast works by building tension and releasing it, similar to how stories naturally flow. Nancy mentions that since sharing this methodology in her 2011 TEDx talk, she has received countless messages from people who achieved remarkable results by restructuring their presentations using this approach.
vocabulary_highlights: cadence of contrast, rise and fall, really astounding

speaker: Nancy Duarte
speaker_expertise: User Experience, Marketing Strategy, Leadership Development
text: We made a mental model he could hold up in his head and the structure was so simple and clear. And then there was three moments where we're like just, I don't know, just grab a piece of paper or go to a whiteboard and just start to draw in front of him. Let him see your eyes, let him have eye contact. Let him see your passion. Don't be dispassionately looking at this computer.
text_ko: 우리는 그가 머릿속에 쉽게 떠올릴 수 있는 멘탈 모델(mental model)을 만들었고, 구조가 아주 단순하고 명확했어요. 그리고 세 번 정도는 '그냥 종이 한 장 집어 들거나 화이트보드로 가서 앞에서 바로 그려 보여줘'라고 우리가 속으로 생각하던 순간들이 있었어요. 눈을 마주치게 하고 눈 맞춤을 유지하세요. 당신의 열정을 보여 주세요. 열정 없이 컴퓨터만 무심하게 바라보지 마세요.
text_zh: 我们给他建了一个思维模型(mental model)，让他脑子里能有个清晰的框架，结构特别简单明了。然后有三个关键时刻，我们就是，怎么说呢，随手拿张纸或者走到白板前，直接在他面前画出来。让他能看到你的眼神，跟他有眼神交流。让他感受到你的热情。别老盯着电脑屏幕，那样太冷冰冰的。
text_es: Creamos un modelo mental que él pudiera visualizar claramente en su cabeza y la estructura era súper simple y clara. Y luego hubo tres momentos donde dijimos, no sé, simplemente agarra una hoja de papel o ve al pizarrón y empieza a dibujar frente a él. Que vea tus ojos, que haya contacto visual. Que vea tu pasión. No te quedes ahí viendo la computadora sin mostrar emoción.
context: Nancy is telling the story of helping an executive from a multinational company who needed to petition his CEO for a $100 million budget. Instead of creating traditional slides, Nancy's team developed a simple mental framework the executive could remember, combined with moments where he would draw key concepts on paper or whiteboards during the meeting. This approach allowed for direct eye contact and emotional connection rather than both people staring at a computer screen during such a high-stakes conversation.
vocabulary_highlights: mental model, hold up in his head, dispassionately looking

speaker: Nancy Duarte
speaker_expertise: User Experience, Marketing Strategy, Leadership Development
text: What happens is they commit to your idea, they commit to your program, your project, and they're like enthused at first. And then they go into the state of, oh my God, this is harder than I thought. It's a long slog. This climb is getting exhausted.
