I don't know if I have this much fight in me to make this all work, not fight with each other, but like, oh my God, I'm having to overcome this roadblock and that roadblock.
text_ko: 처음엔 아이디어나 프로그램, 프로젝트에 헌신하고 신나해요. 그런데 곧 '세상에, 생각보다 훨씬 어렵네'라는 상태가 돼요. 긴 고행 같고, 오르는 게 점점 지치게 만들어요. '이걸 다 해낼 만큼 내 안에 싸울 힘이 있을까' 하고 의심하게 되죠. 여기서 서로 싸우자는 얘기가 아니라, '세상에, 이 장애물 저 장애물을 계속 넘어야 하네' 하는 그런 심정이에요.
text_zh: 情况是这样的，他们一开始对你的想法、你的方案、你的项目特别有信心，也很有热情。但是后来就变成了，天哪，这比我想象的要难多了。这是个漫长的硬仗啊。爬这座山都快累死了。我不知道自己还有没有这么大的精力把这事儿搞定，不是说跟别人斗，而是天哪，这个坎儿得过，那个坎儿也得过。
text_es: Lo que pasa es que se comprometen con tu idea, se comprometen con tu programa, tu proyecto, y al principio están súper motivados. Pero después entran en esa fase de "ay, Dios mío, esto está mucho más difícil de lo que pensé." Es como una caminata larguísima. Esta subida los tiene agotados. No saben si tienen la energía suficiente para hacer que todo esto funcione - no me refiero a pelearse entre ellos, sino más bien ese "ay, no manches, tengo que superar este obstáculo y después ese otro obstáculo."
context: Nancy is explaining the 'fight and climb' phase from her book 'Illuminate,' which describes how to lead people through major organizational changes. She's describing the predictable pattern that occurs after people initially commit to a new initiative - they start enthusiastic but then encounter the difficult middle phase where the work becomes harder than expected. Nancy explains this isn't about interpersonal conflict, but rather the struggle of overcoming obstacles and maintaining momentum during challenging transformational work.
vocabulary_highlights: long slog, this much fight in me, overcome this roadblock

speaker: Naomi Gleit
text: When I got to Facebook, I knew I wanted to build. As someone who wasn't really technical, I wasn't going to be an engineer or a coder. I wanted to work with the engineers and the coders to build products. I thought product management was the right function for me, and so my dream was always to be a PM and it wasn't luck as to how I ended up becoming a PM.
text_ko: 제가 페이스북에 갔을 때, 뭔가를 만들고 싶다는 걸 알았어요. 기술적인 배경이 없는 저로서는 엔지니어나 코더가 될 수는 없었고, 엔지니어들과 코더들과 함께 제품을 만들고 싶었어요. 그래서 제품 관리(product management)가 저한테 맞는 역할이라고 생각했고, 항상 PM이 되는 게 제 꿈이었어요. 결국 PM이 된 건 운이 아니라는 걸 확신해요.
text_zh: 我到Facebook的时候，就知道自己想做产品。我本身不是技术出身，当不了工程师或者程序员。但我想跟工程师和程序员一起合作，把产品做出来。我觉得产品管理这个岗位很适合我，所以我一直的目标就是当PM(product manager)，我能做上PM不是运气好，是有规划的。
text_es: Cuando llegué a Facebook, sabía que quería construir cosas. Como no era muy técnica, no iba a ser ingeniera ni programadora. Quería trabajar con los ingenieros y programadores para desarrollar productos. Pensé que la gestión de productos era lo mío, así que mi sueño siempre fue ser PM (product manager) y no fue casualidad que terminara siendo PM.
context: Lenny asks Naomi about her journey from landing at Facebook as employee #29 to becoming a product manager. Naomi explains that even though she started in a marketing role, she always knew she wanted to work on building products. She describes how she systematically worked toward her goal of becoming a PM by volunteering to help with product projects after her regular work hours, essentially doing the job before she officially got it.
vocabulary_highlights: wasn't luck as to how, right function for me

speaker: Naomi Gleit
text: I ended up going, sort of the analogy, I went to the second floor most days after work, asked if there were any projects that I could help out with. It was very early days. There was always more to do than people to do it. And so eventually I picked up a few projects, helping with program management, giving my product feedback, and by the time that I actually applied formally to be a product manager, I had been doing the job voluntarily, almost informally for a few months.
text_ko: 결국, 비유하자면 퇴근 후 거의 매일 2층에 올라가서 도와줄 프로젝트가 있냐고 물어보곤 했어요. 초기 단계라 할 일이 사람보다 항상 많았어요. 그래서 결국 몇몇 프로젝트를 맡아 프로그램 관리(program management)를 돕고 제품 피드백(product feedback)도 주게 됐어요. 정식으로 제품 매니저(product manager)로 지원할 때쯤에는 이미 몇 달 동안 자발적으로, 거의 비공식적으로 그 일을 해오고 있었어요.
text_zh: 我当时就是，打个比方吧，基本上每天下班后都会跑到二楼去问问有没有什么项目能帮上忙的。那时候公司刚起步，活儿总是比人多，永远忙不过来。慢慢地我就接了几个项目，帮着做项目管理，提一些产品建议什么的。等到我真正正式申请产品经理这个职位的时候，其实我已经义务干了好几个月了，虽然没有正式的头衔，但基本上就是在做这个工作。
text_es: Terminé haciendo algo así como... para que me entiendas, me iba al segundo piso casi todos los días después del trabajo, preguntando si había algún proyecto en el que pudiera echar una mano. Era muy al principio de todo. Siempre había más trabajo que gente para hacerlo. Y bueno, poco a poco fui agarrando algunos proyectos, ayudando con la gestión de programas, dando mi feedback sobre productos, y cuando por fin apliqué formalmente para ser product manager, ya llevaba varios meses haciendo el trabajo de manera voluntaria, casi informal.
context: Naomi continues explaining how she transitioned from marketing to product management at Facebook. She describes her strategy of volunteering for PM-related work after hours - literally going to the second floor where PMs worked and asking to help with projects. Because it was early days at Facebook with limited resources, there was always extra work available, allowing her to gain PM experience before formally applying for the role.
vocabulary_highlights: picked up a few projects, applied formally

speaker: Naomi Gleit
text: So I've always said that there is the biggest gap of anybody I know between what people think of Mark and who Mark really is. And so I think this is the Mark that I've known for the past 20 years and the world is finally getting to see what I've been lucky enough to see. And that gap that we've talked about is really starting to close.
text_ko: 제가 항상 말해온 건, 제가 아는 사람들 중에서 마크에 대해 사람들이 생각하는 것과 실제 마크 사이에 가장 큰 간극이 있다는 거예요. 제가 지난 20년 동안 알던 마크가 바로 이 사람인데, 이제 세상도 제가 운 좋게 봐온 모습을 드디어 보기 시작한 것 같아요. 우리가 얘기해온 그 간극이 정말로 좁혀지기 시작하고 있어요.
text_zh: 所以我一直都说，在我认识的所有人当中，马克给大家的印象和他本人的差距是最大的。我觉得这就是我这20年来认识的那个马克，现在全世界终于能看到我有幸看到的那一面了。我们之前说的那个差距，现在真的开始缩小了。
text_es: Siempre he dicho que Mark es la persona con la mayor diferencia que conozco entre lo que la gente piensa de él y cómo es en realidad. Creo que este es el Mark que he conocido durante los últimos 20 años y el mundo por fin está empezando a ver lo que yo he tenido la suerte de ver. Esa brecha de la que hemos hablado realmente se está empezando a cerrar.
context: Lenny asks Naomi about Mark Zuckerberg's transformation in recent years, noting how he's become much cooler and more charismatic publicly. Naomi explains that this isn't actually a transformation - it's the real Mark that she's always known becoming more visible to the public. She attributes this to Mark becoming more comfortable and confident in public speaking and showing his authentic personality rather than being scripted and careful.
vocabulary_highlights: biggest gap of anybody I know, lucky enough to see, starting to close

speaker: Naomi Gleit
text: And the most precious person in an organization is the disagreeable giver. Those are the people who are really motivated to do what's best for the company, but they can be a little bit disagreeable in the sense that they may not say what you want to hear. They may push back on things, they may fight for things.
text_ko: 조직에서 가장 소중한 사람은 'disagreeable giver'(반대하면서도 기여하는 사람)이에요. 이런 사람들은 회사에 가장 이로운 일을 하려고 진짜 동기가 강한데, 듣기 좋은 말만 하진 않아요. 때로는 반박도 하고, 필요하면 어떤 일에 대해 싸워가며 밀어붙이기도 해요.
text_zh: 组织里最宝贵的人其实是那些"不好说话的给予者"。这些人是真心想为公司好的，但他们可能不太好相处，因为他们不会只说你爱听的话。该反对的时候他们会反对，该争取的时候他们会据理力争。
text_es: Y la persona más valiosa en una organización es el que da pero incomoda. Son esas personas que realmente están motivadas a hacer lo mejor para la empresa, pero pueden ser un poco incómodas en el sentido de que tal vez no te digan lo que quieres escuchar. Pueden cuestionar las cosas, pueden pelear por sus ideas.
context: Naomi is explaining the composition of Mark Zuckerberg's leadership team (called 'small group') and why it works so effectively. She references Adam Grant's framework about agreeable vs. disagreeable people and givers vs. takers. She explains that the most dangerous person is an 'agreeable taker' (nice but self-interested) while the most valuable is a 'disagreeable giver' - someone who will challenge ideas and push back when necessary because they're motivated by what's best for the company.
vocabulary_highlights: most precious person, push back on things, fight for things

speaker: Naomi Gleit
text: What we found was the churn in resurrection lines were actually much larger than the new user line, which implied to us that retention and driving those two lines was actually our biggest lever to drive net growth.
text_ko: 우리가 발견한 건 부활 라인(resurrection lines)의 이탈률(churn)이 신규 유저 라인(new user line)보다 훨씬 컸다는 거예요. 그래서 리텐션(retention)과 이 두 라인을 끌어올리는 것이 순성장(net growth)을 만드는 가장 큰 레버(lever)라는 결론을 내렸어요.
text_zh: 我们发现复活用户线(resurrection lines)的流失其实比新用户线大得多，这说明用户留存和推动这两条线的增长，才是我们实现净增长最重要的抓手。
text_es: Lo que descubrimos fue que la rotación en las líneas de resurrección era en realidad mucho mayor que en la línea de usuarios nuevos, lo cual nos indicó que la retención y el impulso de esas dos líneas era realmente nuestra palanca más importante para generar crecimiento neto.
context: Naomi is explaining Facebook's legendary growth team approach and how they discovered the importance of retention. She describes their 'growth accounting' framework which tracked daily net growth as new users minus users who went stale plus users who 'resurrected' (returned after 30 days of inactivity). This analysis revealed that user retention was a much bigger factor in growth than acquisition, leading to their focus on engagement metrics like the famous '7 friends in 10 days' activation goal.
vocabulary_highlights: churn in resurrection lines, biggest lever to drive

speaker: Naomi Gleit
text: One of my Naomi-isms is really understand, identify, and execute. That framework came from 2009 where the growth team at the time, it was fledgling and it just started, was focused on only instrumenting data.
text_ko: 제가 자주 하는 나오미식 표현 중 하나는 "정확히 이해하고, 파악하고, 실행하는 거예요." 그 프레임워크(framework)는 2009년에 나온 거예요. 당시 성장팀(growth team)은 막 시작한 초창기 팀이라 데이터 계측(data instrumentation)에만 집중하고 있었어요.
text_zh: 我有个口头禅叫"真正理解、识别、然后执行"。这个思路是2009年形成的，当时增长团队(growth team)刚起步，还很不成熟，只知道埋头收集数据。
text_es: Una de mis "naomismos" es realmente entender, identificar y ejecutar. Ese marco de trabajo surgió en 2009 cuando el equipo de growth (crecimiento) en ese momento, que apenas estaba empezando y era muy incipiente, se enfocaba únicamente en instrumentar datos.
context: Naomi is sharing one of her key frameworks for product development. She explains that in 2009, Facebook's growth team realized they lacked the data needed to make informed decisions about growth levers. So they stopped all other work to focus exclusively on 'instrumenting data' - adding tracking and measurement to every step of user flows like registration and onboarding. This 'understand, identify, execute' approach became fundamental: first understand through data, then identify the biggest opportunities, then execute solutions.
vocabulary_highlights: it was fledgling, instrumenting data

speaker: Naomi Gleit
text: I really believe in frameworks for things that helps drive extreme clarity. I work on a lot of different projects. A lot of times I'm ramping up a new project, I'm like, 'Where can I learn what I need to learn about this project?' I ask five different people, get five different answers. That is unacceptable.
text_ko: 저는 사안을 아주 분명하게 해 주는 프레임워크(framework)를 정말 믿어요. 저는 다양한 프로젝트를 많이 진행해요. 새 프로젝트를 본격적으로 시작할 때(ramping up)면 항상 "이 프로젝트에 대해 제가 알아야 할 걸 어디서 배우지?"라고 생각해요. 다섯 명에게 물어보면 다섯 가지 다른 답을 듣게 되는데, 그건 용납할 수 없어요.
text_zh: 我特别相信用框架来做事，这样能让思路特别清晰。我手头项目很多，经常要启动新项目的时候，我就想"我得去哪儿了解这个项目需要掌握的东西？"结果问五个人，得到五个不同的答案。这绝对不行。
text_es: De verdad creo mucho en tener marcos de trabajo para las cosas que te ayuden a lograr una claridad total. Trabajo en un montón de proyectos diferentes. Muchas veces cuando estoy arrancando un proyecto nuevo, me pregunto: "¿Dónde puedo aprender lo que necesito saber sobre este proyecto?" Le pregunto a cinco personas diferentes y recibo cinco respuestas distintas. Eso es inaceptable.
context: This is the opening quote where Naomi introduces her philosophy about the importance of frameworks and what she calls 'extreme clarity.' She's explaining a common problem in complex organizations where different people give different answers about the same project, which creates confusion and inefficiency. This leads into her concept of 'canonical everything' - having one definitive source of truth for every project.
vocabulary_highlights: drive extreme clarity, ramping up, that is unacceptable

speaker: Naomi Ionita
text: Do not set it and forget it. I see companies do this, where they labor over designs and features. And they build this perfect product that's delightful to use. And then pricing's sort of plucked out of thin air, and then they don't revisit it. This was Evernote. It was many, many years before we went back and overhauled the pricing. So, think about your pricing just like you do your roadmap. Every 6 to 12 months, there's probably something meaningful that you're launching for users. So, treat that as an opportunity to revisit your monetization strategy and making sure you're compensated appropriately.
text_ko: 그냥 한 번 정해놓고 잊어버리지 마세요. 많은 회사가 디자인과 기능에는 엄청 공들여서 사용하기 즐거운 완벽한 제품을 만들고도, 가격은 마치 공중에서 뚝 떨어뜨리듯 대충 정해놓고는 다시 들여다보지 않더라고요. 에버노트도 그랬어요. 가격을 전면적으로 손보기까지 정말 오래 걸렸습니다. 그러니까 가격 정책(pricing)은 로드맵(roadmap)처럼 생각하세요. 보통 6~12개월마다 사용자에게 내놓을 의미 있는 업데이트가 하나쯤은 있으니, 그때를 수익화 전략(monetization strategy)을 다시 점검하고 우리가 적절한 보상을 받고 있는지 확인하는 기회로 삼으세요.
text_zh: 别搞成一锤子买卖就不管了。我见过很多公司都这样，在设计和功能上下足了功夫，做出来的产品体验特别棒，用户用着很爽。但定价呢？基本就是拍脑袋决定的，定完就再也不碰了。Evernote就是这样，我们过了好多年才回头重新整理定价策略。所以啊，你得像对待产品路线图一样认真对待定价。每隔6到12个月，你肯定会给用户推出一些有意义的新功能对吧？那就把这当成重新审视变现策略(monetization strategy)的机会，确保你的收费是合理的。
text_es: No lo pongas en piloto automático y te olvides. Veo empresas que hacen esto, donde se matan diseñando funciones y características. Construyen este producto perfecto, súper fácil de usar. Y después el precio como que lo sacan de la nada, y ya nunca más lo tocan. Eso nos pasó en Evernote. Pasaron muchísimos años antes de que volviéramos a revisar toda la estrategia de precios. Entonces, piensa en tus precios igual que piensas en tu roadmap. Cada 6 a 12 meses, seguramente estás lanzando algo importante para los usuarios. Aprovecha esos momentos para revisar tu estrategia de monetización y asegurarte de que te estén pagando lo que realmente vale.
context: This quote appears to be from Naomi's opening remarks about pricing strategies. She is emphasizing the importance of regularly updating and iterating on pricing decisions rather than making initial pricing choices and never revisiting them. Using Evernote as an example where she previously worked, Naomi explains how companies often spend extensive effort perfecting product features but neglect to strategically approach pricing, often making arbitrary initial pricing decisions and then failing to optimize them over time.
vocabulary_highlights: set it and forget it, labor over, plucked out of thin air, compensated appropriately

speaker: Naomi Ionita
text: Evernote was philosophically antisocial. It was meant to be your second brain, kind of your personal tool. And I think that capped the company's growth potential. I always used to say you can't retrofit collaboration. You have to be collaboration-first. And a lot of companies now really take that for granted. But back in mid-2000s, this was kind of a new way of building product. And so we missed that bridge.
text_ko: Evernote는 근본적으로 사람들과 같이 쓰는 방향이 아니었어요. 개인용 도구, 일종의 두 번째 뇌(second brain)로 쓰이게 만든 제품이었고요. 그래서 그게 회사의 성장 가능성을 제한했다고 생각해요. 저는 항상 "협업은 나중에 억지로 끼워 넣을 수 없다"라고 말했어요 — 애초부터 협업 우선(collaboration-first)으로 설계해야 해요. 지금은 많은 회사들이 그걸 당연하게 여기지만, 2000년대 중반에는 이런 식으로 제품을 만드는 게 꽤 새로웠어요. 그래서 우리는 그 기회를 놓치고 말았어요.
text_zh: Evernote在理念上就是反社交的。它本来就是要做你的第二大脑，算是你的个人工具吧。我觉得这就限制了公司的增长空间。我以前经常说，协作功能你没法后来再加上去，必须一开始就以协作为核心来做。现在很多公司都觉得这是理所当然的，但在2000年代中期，这种产品思路还算挺新的。所以我们就错过了这个机会。
text_es: Evernote tenía una filosofía antisocial, por así decirlo. Estaba pensado para ser tu segundo cerebro, como una herramienta personal. Y creo que eso limitó el potencial de crecimiento de la empresa. Yo siempre decía que no puedes añadir colaboración después del hecho. Tienes que pensar en colaboración desde el primer día. Y muchas empresas ahora dan eso por sentado. Pero allá por mediados de los 2000, esta era una forma bastante nueva de construir productos. Y por eso perdimos esa oportunidad.
context: Lenny asks Naomi about Evernote's recent sale and why they didn't become as successful as Notion. Naomi explains that Evernote struggled to evolve from a single-player personal productivity tool to a collaborative multiplayer platform. She describes how Evernote was designed as an individual's 'second brain' but failed to successfully transition to team collaboration, which limited its growth potential and prevented it from capturing the enterprise market that tools like Notion eventually dominated.
vocabulary_highlights: philosophically antisocial, second brain, retrofit collaboration, collaboration-first, take that for granted

speaker: Naomi Ionita
text: Our additional research helped us understand that brand-new users with low perceived value of Evernote looked at it like their Apple Notepad app that was pre-installed on their device. And so, they couldn't understand the idea of paying $45 for Evernote. But then we talked to avid users, and these were people that were cross client using it on desktop and mobile, every device they had. They were using it for work and personal, they were leveraging OCR capabilities and the web clipper, and it was truly their second brain. They could not imagine life without it. And these people were floored that they were only paying $45 a year. They told us that they were getting hundreds of value from Evernote.
text_ko: 추가 조사에서 새로운 사용자들 중 Evernote의 가치를 낮게 느끼는 사람들은 기기에 기본으로 깔려 있는 Apple의 메모 앱(Apple Notepad app) 정도로만 생각한다는 걸 알게 됐어요. 그래서 Evernote에 연간 $45를 내야 한다는 걸 이해하지 못했죠. 반면에 열성 사용자들은 데스크톱과 모바일 등 모든 기기에서 크로스-클라이언트로 사용(cross client)했고, 업무와 개인 용도로 모두 활용하면서 OCR 기능(OCR)과 웹 클리퍼(web clipper)를 적극적으로 쓰며 사실상 '두 번째 뇌'(second brain)처럼 쓰고 있었어요. 이분들은 연 $45만 내고 있다는 사실에 깜짝 놀랐고, Evernote로부터 수백 달러에 달하는 가치를 얻고 있다고 말했어요.
text_zh: 我们进一步的调研让我们发现，那些刚开始用印象笔记(Evernote)、觉得这产品没什么价值的新用户，基本上就把它当成苹果手机自带的那个备忘录app。所以他们完全理解不了为什么要花45美金买印象笔记。但是呢，我们又去跟那些重度用户聊了聊，这些人真的是全平台在用——电脑上用，手机上用，各种设备都在用。他们工作用它，生活也用它，OCR识别、网页剪藏(web clipper)这些功能都在用，印象笔记真的就是他们的第二个大脑。他们说完全没法想象没有它的生活会是什么样。而且这些人听说一年才45美金的时候都惊呆了，他们跟我们说从印象笔记身上得到的价值起码有几百美金。
text_es: Nuestra investigación adicional nos ayudó a entender que los usuarios completamente nuevos que veían poco valor en Evernote lo comparaban con la app de Notas de Apple que ya venía instalada en su dispositivo. Entonces, no entendían por qué pagar 45 dólares por Evernote. Pero luego hablamos con usuarios súper activos, gente que lo usaba en todos lados - computadora, celular, todos sus dispositivos. Lo usaban tanto para el trabajo como para cosas personales, aprovechaban las funciones de OCR y el web clipper, y realmente era como su segundo cerebro. No se imaginaban la vida sin él. Y esta gente no podía creer que solo estuviera pagando 45 dólares al año. Nos decían que para ellos Evernote valía cientos de dólares.
context: Naomi is explaining research they conducted at Evernote to understand different user segments and their willingness to pay. She discovered that Evernote had a single pricing tier that didn't match the varied value different users received from the product. Through surveys and user research, they found that casual users saw minimal value while power users who used advanced features across multiple devices felt the product was significantly underpriced, indicating a need for segmented pricing tiers.
vocabulary_highlights: avid users, cross client, leveraging OCR capabilities, web clipper, were floored

speaker: Naomi Ionita
text: The beginning of a startup's journey is all about creating something of value. Right? That's the whole point. Hopefully, founders have some unique market insight or some authenticity around a pain point and some novel solution that's going to change the world. So, that business value is really critical. But the other side of the same coin is being properly compensated for that value as a business. I understand the vulnerability of being a new startup. You just want people to use your product. And I view that early free beta user feedback loop as an R&D cost to make sure you're building the best possible product and that they're driving a lot of value.
text_ko: 스타트업(startup) 여정의 시작은 결국 가치 있는 무언가를 만들어내는 거예요. 그게 본질이죠. 바라건대 창업자들(founders)은 독특한 시장 통찰력(market insight)이나 그 고충(pain point)에 대한 진정성 있는 이해, 그리고 세상을 바꿀 만한 새로운 해결책을 가지고 있겠죠. 그래서 그 비즈니스 가치(business value)가 정말 중요해요. 그런데 같은 동전의 다른 면은 그 가치를 비즈니스로서 적절히 보상받는 거예요. 새로운 스타트업(startup)이 얼마나 취약한지는 이해해요 — 일단은 사람들이 제품을 써주길 바랄 테니까요. 그리고 저는 초기 무료 베타 사용자 피드백 루프(beta user feedback loop)를 최고의 제품을 만들고 사용자가 실제로 큰 가치를 얻고 있는지 확인하기 위한 R&D 비용(R&D cost)으로 봐요.
text_zh: 创业刚开始的时候，核心就是要做出有价值的东西，对吧？这就是重点所在。理想情况下，创始人应该对市场有独特的洞察，或者对某个痛点有真切的体会，再加上一个能改变世界的新颖解决方案。所以说，商业价值确实很关键。但硬币的另一面就是，作为一家公司，你得为这个价值拿到应有的回报。我理解新创业公司的脆弱处境——你就是希望有人用你的产品。我把早期免费内测用户的反馈循环(feedback loop)看作是研发成本，这样能确保你做出最好的产品，让用户真正获得价值。
text_es: Al principio del camino de una startup, todo se trata de crear algo que tenga valor. ¿No? Ese es todo el punto. Con suerte, los fundadores tienen alguna perspectiva única del mercado o cierta autenticidad alrededor de un punto de dolor y alguna solución novedosa que va a cambiar el mundo. Entonces, ese valor del negocio es súper crítico. Pero el otro lado de la misma moneda es que te compensen bien por ese valor como empresa. Entiendo lo vulnerable que es ser una startup nueva. Solo quieres que la gente use tu producto. Y veo ese bucle de feedback temprano de usuarios beta gratis como un costo de I+D para asegurarme de que estés construyendo el mejor producto posible y que realmente estén generando mucho valor.
context: Lenny asks about common mistakes startups make with monetization, and Naomi is addressing the first major mistake: waiting too long to start charging for their product. She acknowledges that startups naturally want to create value and get users, but emphasizes that being compensated for that value is equally important. She explains how founders can think of early free usage as a research and development investment, but warns against extending this free period too long and missing the opportunity to build a sustainable business model.
vocabulary_highlights: other side of the same coin, properly compensated, novel solution, R&D cost

speaker: Naomi Ionita
text: Our friends at OpenView do a really good job of pumping out content and doing these great SaaS benchmarking surveys. They did something recently that showed that roughly half of companies that instituted a pricing change saw at least a 25% increase in ARR. So that's a pretty massive step function improvement in your revenue from something that doesn't require massive technological overhaul. I find that most companies regret not doing it sooner.
text_ko: OpenView 쪽 분들이 콘텐츠를 잘 만들어내고 훌륭한 SaaS 벤치마킹 설문조사(SaaS benchmarking surveys)를 꾸준히 하더라고요. 최근 조사에서 가격 정책을 바꾼 회사의 약 절반이 연간 반복수익(ARR)이 최소 25% 이상 늘었다고 해요. 기술을 대대적으로 바꿀 필요 없이 수익이 이렇게 크게 뛰는 건 꽤 놀라운 결과예요. 대부분의 회사들은 더 일찍 하지 않은 걸 후회하더라고요.
text_zh: 我们OpenView的朋友们在产出内容和做SaaS基准调研(benchmarking surveys)方面真的很厉害。他们最近搞了个调研，结果显示大概有一半调整过定价的公司，年经常性收入(ARR)至少涨了25%。这个提升幅度相当可观，关键是不用大动干戈地改技术架构什么的。我发现大部分公司都后悔没早点这么干。
text_es: Nuestros amigos de OpenView hacen un trabajo excelente creando contenido y llevando a cabo estas encuestas de benchmarking para SaaS que están buenísimas. Hace poco hicieron algo que mostró que aproximadamente la mitad de las empresas que implementaron un cambio de precios vieron por lo menos un aumento del 25% en su ARR. O sea, es una mejora brutal en tus ingresos que viene de algo que no requiere una reestructuración tecnológica masiva. Me doy cuenta de que la mayoría de las empresas se arrepienten de no haberlo hecho antes.
context: Lenny asks Naomi about the potential impact of making pricing changes and how to experiment with pricing. Naomi cites research from OpenView, a venture capital firm, to demonstrate the significant revenue impact that pricing optimizations can have. She emphasizes that pricing changes can deliver substantial returns without requiring major product development or technical changes, making it one of the most efficient ways to improve business performance.
vocabulary_highlights: pumping out content, instituted a pricing change, step function improvement, massive technological overhaul

speaker: Naomi Ionita
text: And in that moment, the exec said, 'Okay, sure. Sounds good.' Not a minute of hesitation, not a second of hesitation. And what he learned in that moment was that, one, he was wildly underpriced. It was very clear that he hadn't even thought about what the ceiling was. But the truth was he probably could have pushed it even further, considering there was no hesitation. So, what I encourage users to do, especially in these enterprise conversations, is to continue to ask for more, to understand where the upper bound might be, and to understand that it's okay sometimes to lose some deals due to price.
text_ko: 그 순간, 임원분이 “좋아요, 괜찮습니다”라고 말했어요. 한 치의 망설임도, 주저함도 전혀 없었죠. 그가 그때 깨달은 건, 첫째로 자신(또는 제품) 가격을 훨씬 낮게 책정해놨다는 거예요. 가격의 상한(ceiling)에 대해 아예 생각해본 적도 없었던 게 확실했어요. 사실 망설임이 없었다는 걸 보면 더 올려도 됐을 가능성이 크고요. 그래서 제가 사용자들에게 권하는 건, 특히 이런 기업 대상 대화(enterprise conversations)에서는 계속 더 요구해보고, 상한(upper bound)이 어디쯤인지 파악해보라는 거예요. 그리고 때로는 가격 때문에 몇 건의 딜(deal)을 놓치는 게 괜찮다는 것도 이해하라고요.
text_zh: 就在那一刻，那个高管说："行，没问题，听起来不错。"一分钟都没犹豫，一秒钟都没犹豫。他在那一刻学到的是，第一，他的定价太低了，低得离谱。很明显他根本没想过天花板在哪儿。但实际上他可能还能要更多，毕竟人家连犹豫都没犹豫。所以我建议大家，特别是在跟大企业谈的时候，要敢于要更多，要摸清楚上限在哪儿，要明白有时候因为价格丢几个单子是完全可以的。
text_es: Y en ese momento, el ejecutivo le dijo: "Vale, perfecto. Me parece bien." Ni un minuto de duda, ni un segundo siquiera. Y lo que se dio cuenta en ese momento fue que, primero, estaba cobrando muy poco. Estaba clarísimo que ni siquiera había pensado cuál era el tope. Pero la verdad es que probablemente podría haber pedido aún más, considerando que no dudó para nada. Entonces, lo que les recomiendo a los usuarios, especialmente en estas conversaciones con empresas grandes, es que sigan pidiendo más, que entiendan dónde puede estar el límite superior, y que entiendan que a veces está bien perder algunos negocios por precio.
context: Naomi is telling a story about Larry from Envoy, a visitor registration tool company. During a sales conversation with a hospitality company prospect, Larry spontaneously decided to ask for 10 times his usual price to test the market. When the executive immediately accepted without hesitation, Larry realized he had been severely underpricing his product. Naomi uses this example to illustrate how founders can test pricing boundaries and shouldn't be afraid to lose some deals to price resistance in order to find the optimal pricing point.
vocabulary_highlights: wildly underpriced, push it even further, upper bound, lose some deals due to price

speaker: Nick Turley
speaker_expertise: AI/ML Products, Growth Strategy, Consumer Products
text: This is a pattern with AI, you won't know what to polish until after you ship. My dream is that we ship daily.
text_ko: AI 쪽에서는 보통 이런 패턴이에요 — 배포(ship)해 보기 전까지는 어느 부분을 다듬어야 할지 잘 모르는 경우가 많아요. 저는 매일 배포하는 게 꿈이에요.
text_zh: 这就是AI的特点，你得先上线了才知道哪里需要优化。我的理想状态就是每天都能发布新版本。
text_es: Este es un patrón típico con la IA, no vas a saber qué pulir hasta después de lanzar. Mi sueño es que lancemos todos los días.
context: Lenny asks Nick about the development philosophy at OpenAI and how they approach product releases. Nick explains that AI products have unique characteristics where the most valuable features and improvements only become clear after users interact with the product in the real world. He emphasizes that unlike traditional software where you can predict user behavior, AI capabilities are often emergent and unpredictable, making rapid iteration essential for learning what actually works.
vocabulary_highlights: pattern with AI, polish, ship daily

speaker: Nick Turley
speaker_expertise: AI/ML Products, Growth Strategy, Consumer Products
text: I just really want to jump to the punchline, 'Why can't we do this now?' I always felt like part of my role here is to just set the pace and the resting heartbeat.
text_ko: 저는 사실 바로 핵심으로 뛰어들어 “이걸 지금 당장 왜 못 해요?”라고 묻고 싶을 때가 많아요. 여기서 제 역할 중 하나는 페이스랑 조직의 기본 리듬을 정하는 거라고 늘 느껴왔어요.
text_zh: 我就是特别想直接说重点，"为什么我们现在就不能做这个事儿？"我一直觉得我在这儿的作用就是要把节奏带起来，让团队保持那种基本的工作状态和活力。
text_es: Solo quiero ir directo al grano, '¿Por qué no podemos hacer esto ya?' Siempre he sentido que parte de mi papel aquí es marcar el ritmo y mantener el pulso constante de la empresa.
context: Lenny asks about Nick's principle of 'maximally accelerated' development that Kevin Weil mentioned. Nick explains his philosophy of cutting through blockers and instilling urgency in teams by always questioning why something can't be done immediately. He describes his role as setting the tempo for the entire organization, using the metaphor of a 'resting heartbeat' to describe the natural pace at which teams operate when not under specific pressure.
vocabulary_highlights: jump to the punchline, set the pace, resting heartbeat

speaker: Nick Turley
speaker_expertise: AI/ML Products, Growth Strategy, Consumer Products
text: I'm baffled by how much it took off, even more baffled by how many people have copied. Chat was the simplest way to ship at that time.
text_ko: 이게 이렇게 크게 뜰 줄은 몰라서 정말 어리둥절하고, 얼마나 많은 사람들이 따라 한 건지는 더 놀라워요. 당시에는 챗(Chat)이 제품을 출시하는 가장 간단한 방법이었어요.
text_zh: 我真没想到这东西会这么火，更没想到会有这么多人跟风抄袭。当时聊天功能是最简单直接的上线方式。
text_es: Me sorprende muchísimo cómo despegó, y me sorprende aún más la cantidad de gente que lo ha copiado. El chat era la forma más sencilla de lanzarlo en ese momento.
context: Lenny asks whether chat interfaces are the future of AI interaction. Nick reflects on the unexpected massive success of ChatGPT's chat interface and expresses surprise that so many competitors simply copied the chat paradigm rather than experimenting with different ways to interact with AI. He reveals that chat was chosen not because it was the optimal interface, but because it was the fastest way to get the product to market and start learning from users.
vocabulary_highlights: baffled, took off

speaker: Nick Turley
speaker_expertise: AI/ML Products, Growth Strategy, Consumer Products
text: ChatGPT feels a little bit like MS-DOS. We haven't built Windows yet, and it will be obvious once we do.
text_ko: ChatGPT는 조금 도스(MS‑DOS) 같은 느낌이에요. 아직 윈도우(Windows)를 만들지 못했는데, 만들고 나면 그게 분명해질 거예요.
text_zh: ChatGPT感觉就像当年的MS-DOS一样。我们还没做出Windows那样的东西，但一旦做出来，大家马上就能看出差别。
text_es: ChatGPT se siente un poco como MS-DOS. Todavía no hemos creado Windows, pero va a ser súper obvio cuando lo hagamos.
context: Lenny asks Nick about the future direction of ChatGPT and what a more evolved version might look like. Nick uses a computer history analogy to explain that the current chat interface, while successful, is still a primitive way to interact with AI - similar to how MS-DOS was functional but not intuitive. He suggests that there will eventually be a breakthrough in AI interface design that will be as transformative as the graphical user interface was to personal computers, making the interaction much more natural and powerful.
vocabulary_highlights: feels a little bit like, obvious once we do

speaker: Nick Turley
speaker_expertise: AI/ML Products, Growth Strategy, Consumer Products
text: Amazing ideas come from anywhere. The thing about running a research lab is you really don't tell people what to research. That's not what you do.
text_ko: 놀라운 아이디어는 어디서든 나와요. 연구실(research lab)을 운영할 때 중요한 건 사람들에게 '뭘 연구하라'고 직접 지시하지 않는다는 거예요. 그건 연구실을 운영하는 사람이 할 일이 아니에요.
text_zh: 好点子哪儿都能冒出来。做研究实验室这一行，你其实不能告诉人家该研究什么，这可不是你的活儿。
text_es: Las ideas increíbles pueden surgir de cualquier lado. Lo que pasa con dirigir un laboratorio de investigación es que en realidad no les dices a las personas qué tienen que investigar. Esa no es tu función.
context: Lenny asks about the most counterintuitive lessons Nick has learned building products at OpenAI compared to traditional tech companies like Dropbox and Instacart. Nick explains how OpenAI inherited a research culture where innovation emerges organically from empowered individuals rather than top-down direction. He contrasts this with typical corporate structures where product managers act as gatekeepers, arguing that OpenAI's approach of letting smart people pursue their ideas has been crucial to their success.
vocabulary_highlights: amazing ideas come from anywhere, research lab

speaker: Nick Turley
speaker_expertise: AI/ML Products, Growth Strategy, Consumer Products
text: You're either in a mode of explorer where you have a bunch of unknowns and you're testing to see whether or not you like it, or you're exploiting, where you actually have found something that's really rich and really deep.
text_ko: 당신은 모르는 게 많은 탐험자(explorer) 모드여서 이게 마음에 드는지 테스트해 보는 중이거나, 아니면 진짜로 풍부하고 깊이 있는 걸 찾아내서 그걸 집중적으로 활용(exploiting)하는 모드에 있어요.
text_zh: 你要么是在探索模式，有一堆未知的东西，测试看看自己到底喜不喜欢；要么就是在挖掘模式，已经找到了真正有价值、很有深度的东西，就专心去做。
text_es: O estás en modo explorador, donde tienes un montón de incógnitas y estás probando a ver si te funciona, o estás en modo de explotación, donde ya encontraste algo que realmente vale la pena y tiene mucho potencial.
context: Lenny asks Nick for advice he'd give to people making career decisions, particularly in light of how Nick followed curiosity and smart people rather than chasing money. Nick explains his philosophy using an 'explore versus exploit' framework borrowed from decision theory. In the exploration phase, you're testing different opportunities to discover what energizes you and where you can excel, while in the exploitation phase, you go deep on something valuable you've already identified.
vocabulary_highlights: mode of explorer, bunch of unknowns, really rich and really deep

speaker: Nick Turley
speaker_expertise: AI/ML Products, Growth Strategy, Consumer Products
text: We set out to build a super assistant. It was supposed to be a hackathon code base.
text_ko: 우리는 슈퍼 어시스턴트(super assistant)를 만들겠다고 나섰어요. 원래는 그냥 해커톤용 코드베이스(hackathon code base)로 그칠 생각이었거든요.
text_zh: 我们当初想做一个超级助手，本来就是个黑客马拉松(hackathon)的代码基础而已。
text_es: Nos propusimos crear un súper asistente. Se suponía que iba a ser solo código de hackathon.
context: Lenny asks about the early origins of ChatGPT and how it evolved from an internal experiment to the most successful consumer product in history. Nick reveals that ChatGPT emerged from a hackathon project where the team was trying to build various AI assistant concepts. The 'super assistant' was their original vision - an AI that could help with any task and understand your goals without requiring detailed explanations each time.
vocabulary_highlights: super assistant, hackathon code base

speaker: Nickey Skarstad
speaker_expertise: Product Strategy, Team Building, Product Management
text: I think especially if you're newer in your PM career, they just have a really great organization. And I think it's a great place to learn how to PM. Also their product, it's a huge scaled product. And so it's complicated to build in. So I think it's a great place to really understand second order systems and systems thinking.
text_ko: 특히 프로덕트 매니저(PM)로 경력이 아직 짧다면 그 회사는 조직이 정말 잘 되어 있어요. PM을 배우기 좋은 곳이에요. 그리고 그 회사의 제품은 규모가 엄청난 제품(huge scaled product)이라서 구축이 복잡해요. 그래서 세컨드 오더 시스템(second-order systems)과 시스템 사고(systems thinking)를 제대로 이해하기에 아주 좋은 곳이라고 생각해요.
text_zh: 我觉得特别是如果你在产品经理这条路上还比较新的话，他们公司组织架构真的很不错。我觉得是个学怎么做产品经理的好地方。还有就是他们的产品，规模特别大，所以在里面开发是很复杂的。我觉得在那里真的能深入理解二阶系统(second order systems)和系统性思维(systems thinking)。
text_es: Creo que especialmente si estás empezando tu carrera como PM, tienen una organización realmente sólida. Y me parece un lugar excelente para aprender a ser PM. Además su producto está a una escala enorme. Y por eso es complicado desarrollar ahí. Entonces creo que es un lugar genial para entender de verdad los sistemas de segundo orden (second order systems) y el pensamiento sistémico (systems thinking).
context: Lenny asks Nickey about her experience at Shopify and whether she'd recommend it to other PMs. Nickey explains that while the platform role wasn't the right fit for her personally, she still thinks Shopify is an excellent company for product managers to work at. She's discussing what makes Shopify valuable for PM career development and skill building.
vocabulary_highlights: second order systems, systems thinking, scaled product

speaker: Nickey Skarstad
speaker_expertise: Product Strategy, Team Building, Product Management
text: I actually went through my calendar and I changed the colors of all of the meetings on my calendar to red, yellow, and green after I had the meeting. And I looked. And basically if it was yellow, I was like, okay. It was a fine meeting. My energy was baseline. If it was red, I was either bored or I was stressed, or I was not having a good time. And if it was green, it gave me energy and I felt excited and I wanted to keep working on that.
text_ko: 사실 저는 캘린더를 쭉 훑으면서 미팅이 끝난 뒤에 모든 미팅을 빨강·노랑·초록으로 색을 바꿔놨어요. 그리고 보니까 기본적으로 노랑이면 그냥 무난한 미팅이었어요. 에너지도 평상시 수준이었고요. 빨강이면 지루했거나 스트레스를 받았거나 기분이 안 좋았고, 초록이면 에너지가 생기고 신나서 그 일을 더 이어가고 싶더라고요.
text_zh: 我真的把我的日历翻了一遍，把所有开完的会议都标上了颜色——红色、黄色、绿色。然后我发现，黄色的会议就是那种还行吧，没什么感觉，就是正常状态。红色的会议要么让我觉得无聊，要么压力特别大，反正就是很难受。绿色的会议就不一样了，开完特别有劲儿，很兴奋，还想继续干下去。
text_es: Decidí revisar mi calendario y cambié los colores de todas las reuniones a rojo, amarillo y verde después de tenerlas. Y me puse a analizar los resultados. Básicamente, si era amarillo, era como "bueno, estuvo bien." La reunión fue normal, mi energía se quedó igual. Si era rojo, o me aburrí muchísimo o me estresé, o la pasé fatal. Y si era verde, me dio energía, me emocioné y me dieron ganas de seguir trabajando en eso.
context: Lenny asks Nickey for advice on how to know if a role or company isn't a good fit. Nickey shares a practical technique she used while at Shopify to evaluate whether her work was energizing her. She describes a color-coding system to track her energy levels after meetings as a way to objectively assess job satisfaction and determine if a role is right for you.
vocabulary_highlights: energy was baseline, gave me energy

speaker: Nickey Skarstad
speaker_expertise: Product Strategy, Team Building, Product Management
text: I've seen a lot of director level people through my career who will try to work on strategy in a vacuum alone. They'll write a document and they'll be like, "Okay, team. Here's what we're doing. Here's our strategy." And it never goes well. And it doesn't go well. It might be the right strategy, but because you did not bring people along on that journey to come up with it, they did not feel like they had a hand in crafting it themselves.
text_ko: 제 경력 동안 혼자서만 전략을 고민하는 디렉터급(director level) 분들을 많이 봐왔어요. 문서를 하나 만들어서는 “자, 팀. 우리가 이렇게 할 거예요. 이게 우리의 전략입니다.” 하고 던져놓죠. 그리고 잘 풀리는 경우는 거의 없어요. 설령 전략 자체는 옳을지라도, 사람들을 그 과정에 함께 끌어들이지 않으면 스스로 그 전략을 만들었다는 느낌을 받지 못해요.
text_zh: 我这些年见过不少总监级别的人，喜欢自己一个人闷头搞战略。他们写完文档就跟团队说："好了大家，我们就这么干，这就是我们的战略。"结果从来没成功过。确实成功不了啊。可能战略本身没问题，但你没有让大家参与到制定过程中来，他们就觉得这事跟自己没关系，不是自己参与做出来的。
text_es: He visto a muchos directores a lo largo de mi carrera que intentan trabajar la estrategia completamente solos, como en una burbuja. Se ponen a escribir un documento y después llegan con el equipo y les dicen: "Bueno, equipo. Esto es lo que vamos a hacer. Esta es nuestra estrategia." Y nunca funciona bien. Por más que sea la estrategia correcta, como no involucraste a la gente en ese proceso para desarrollarla, no sienten que tuvieron participación en crearla.
context: Lenny asks Nickey about her approach to setting vision, translating it into goals, and executing on those goals - something she's known for doing well. Nickey is explaining her first principle for strategy work, which is to involve the team in the process rather than working alone. She's describing a common mistake she's observed where leaders create strategy in isolation.
vocabulary_highlights: work on strategy in a vacuum, bring people along on that journey, had a hand in crafting it

speaker: Nickey Skarstad
speaker_expertise: Product Strategy, Team Building, Product Management
text: And I actually think that had they launched experiences inside of the Etsy style of organizational structure, it never would've succeeded because it had such a unique business need, and it needed its own process and ways of building product, et cetera. And because they sort of, hate to say wall it off, because it wasn't fully walled off, but because they gave it its own space and its own structure, it allowed it to succeed because they were able to fund it in the right way, give it the resources that it needed, et cetera.
text_ko: 솔직히 그 경험들을 Etsy 스타일의 조직 구조(Etsy-style organizational structure) 안에서 론칭했더라면 성공하지 못했을 거라고 생각해요. 그건 비즈니스 요구가 워낙 특이해서 자체 프로세스(process)와 제품을 만드는 방식(ways of building product) 같은 것들이 따로 필요했거든요. '벽을 쳐놨다'고 말하기는 좀 그런데(wall it off), 완전히 분리된 건 아니었지만, 따로 공간과 구조를 줘서 적절한 방식으로 자금을 지원받고(fund it) 필요한 자원도 받게 해 준 덕분에 성공할 수 있었어요.
text_zh: 我觉得如果他们当时在Etsy那套组织架构下推出体验产品，肯定做不成，因为这个业务太特殊了，需要有自己的流程和产品开发方式。虽然不能说是完全隔离吧，但他们给了这个项目独立的空间和架构，这样才能成功，因为可以用合适的方式给资金，提供需要的资源什么的。
text_es: Y la verdad es que creo que si hubieran lanzado las experiencias dentro de la estructura organizacional típica de Etsy, nunca habría funcionado porque tenía necesidades de negocio muy particulares, y necesitaba sus propios procesos y formas de desarrollar producto, y todo eso. Y como que... no me gusta decir que lo separaron completamente, porque no fue así, pero como le dieron su propio espacio y su propia estructura, eso permitió que tuviera éxito porque pudieron financiarlo de la manera correcta, darle los recursos que necesitaba, y todo eso.
context: Lenny asks Nickey about different organizational structures for product teams, comparing functional versus GM (general manager) models. Nickey is explaining why the GM structure worked well for Airbnb Experiences, where she worked as the first product manager. She's contrasting how Airbnb's GM approach for Experiences differed from Etsy's functional structure and why that was crucial for the new product's success.
vocabulary_highlights: wall it off, gave it its own space, fund it in the right way

speaker: Nickey Skarstad
speaker_expertise: Product Strategy, Team Building, Product Management
text: And so we actually put more friction in the onboarding flow to help to start to solve for that. So we actually slowed you down. We made you be more thoughtful about what you were listing. And by doing that, we actually helped you get to a first sale faster. And so that was another good example of a quality metric that we used, which was, I think it was first sale in seven days.
text_ko: 그래서 그걸 해결하기 위해 온보딩 플로우(onboarding flow)에 오히려 마찰을 더 넣었어요. 그래서 실제로 속도를 늦추고 사용자가 무엇을 올릴지 더 신중하게 생각하게 만들었어요. 그렇게 하니까 오히려 첫 판매에 더 빨리 도달할 수 있게 도왔어요. 그게 우리가 쓴 또 다른 좋은 품질 지표(quality metric)의 예였는데, 아마 7일 내 첫 판매(first sale in seven days)였던 것 같아요.
text_zh: 所以我们其实在用户引导流程(onboarding flow)里故意增加了一些阻力来解决这个问题。我们就是让你慢下来，让你更仔细地思考你要发布什么东西。这样做的结果是，你反而能更快地完成第一笔交易。这就是我们用的另一个很好的质量指标(quality metric)的例子，好像是七天内完成首单这个指标。
text_es: Y entonces lo que hicimos fue meter más fricción en el proceso de incorporación (onboarding) para empezar a solucionar eso. O sea, te ralentizamos a propósito. Te hicimos pensar más detenidamente en lo que estabas publicando. Y haciendo eso, en realidad te ayudamos a conseguir tu primera venta más rápido. Y ese fue otro buen ejemplo de una métrica de calidad que usamos, que era, creo que era primera venta en siete días.
context: Lenny asks about quality metrics that help maintain product quality. Nickey is sharing an example from Etsy where she worked on seller onboarding. She explains how they discovered that optimizing purely for shop openings actually hurt downstream metrics - sellers weren't getting their first sale quickly enough. The solution was counterintuitive: adding friction to make sellers more thoughtful about their listings, which improved their success rate.
vocabulary_highlights: put more friction, slowed you down, solve for that

speaker: Nickey Skarstad
speaker_expertise: Product Strategy, Team Building, Product Management
text: The decisions you make today will affect tomorrow's decisions and your ability to build on your decisions that you made today. And this feels very existential and meta, but why it's important is that, especially when you're building product, is there's a cost associated with your time of everything you build. Especially when you're building marketplaces or anything with UGC content. When you make a change today, and it impacts every single user in your ecosystem that then is going to act on that change, it's really hard to make those changes later.
text_ko: 오늘 내리는 결정은 내일의 결정뿐 아니라, 오늘 한 결정을 바탕으로 더 쌓아갈 수 있는 능력에도 영향을 줘요. 존재론적이고 메타하게 느껴지긴 하지만, 중요한 이유는 특히 제품을 개발할 때 만든 모든 것에는 시간이라는 비용이 따르기 때문이에요. 특히 마켓플레이스(marketplaces)나 사용자 생성 콘텐츠(UGC)를 다루는 서비스일수록 더 그래요. 오늘 어떤 변경을 하면 그 변경이 생태계(ecosystem) 안의 모든 사용자에게 영향을 주고, 그 사람들이 그 변경에 맞춰 행동하게 되죠. 그래서 나중에 그걸 바꾸는 건 정말 어려워요.
text_zh: 你今天做的决策会影响明天的决策，也会影响你在今天决策基础上继续发展的能力。这听起来很哲学很抽象，但为什么重要呢？特别是做产品的时候，你构建的每样东西都有时间成本。尤其是做市场平台(marketplace)或者任何涉及用户生成内容(UGC)的产品时。你今天做一个改动，会影响到生态系统里的每个用户，然后他们都会基于这个改动去行动，这样一来后面再想改就特别难了。
text_es: Las decisiones que tomes hoy van a impactar las decisiones de mañana y tu capacidad para construir sobre lo que decidiste hoy. Y sí, suena muy existencial y abstracto, pero es súper importante porque, sobre todo cuando estás desarrollando producto, cada cosa que construyes te cuesta tiempo. Especialmente cuando estás armando marketplaces o cualquier cosa con contenido UGC (user-generated content). Cuando haces un cambio hoy que afecta a cada usuario de tu ecosistema y todos van a reaccionar a ese cambio, después es re difícil modificar esas cosas.
context: Lenny asks Nickey to explain her concept of second order decision-making, which she has written about in her newsletter. Nickey is defining what second order thinking means - the ability to think beyond immediate decisions to understand how today's choices will impact future decisions and the broader system. She's explaining why this is particularly important for product managers working on complex systems like marketplaces.
vocabulary_highlights: very existential and meta, there's a cost associated, UGC content

speaker: Nicole Forsgren
text: Most productivity metrics are a lie. If the goal is more lines of code, I can prompt something to write the longest piece of code ever. It's just too easy to gain that system.
text_ko: 사실 대부분의 생산성 지표(productivity metrics)는 속임수예요. 목표가 코드 라인 수(lines of code)를 늘리는 것이라면, 가장 긴 코드를 쓰게 만드는 프롬프트(prompt)를 얼마든지 만들 수 있어요. 그런 식으로 시스템을 조작(game the system)하는 건 너무 쉬워요.
text_zh: 大部分生产力指标都是扯淡。如果目标是写更多代码行数，我随便找个工具就能生成史上最长的代码。这种系统太好钻空子了。
text_es: La mayoría de las métricas de productividad son pura mentira. Si el objetivo es más líneas de código, puedo pedirle a cualquier herramienta que me escriba el código más largo del mundo. Es súper fácil manipular ese sistema.
context: Lenny asks Nicole about how companies are measuring productivity for their teams in the age of AI. Nicole explains that traditional productivity metrics like lines of code have become meaningless with AI tools because they can be easily gamed. She points out that AI agents and LLMs tend to be very verbose by default, making it trivial to generate large amounts of code that may introduce complexity and technical debt rather than actual value.
vocabulary_highlights: gain that system, too easy to gain

speaker: Nicole Forsgren
text: Most teams can move faster. But faster for what? We can ship trash faster every single day. We need strategy and really smart decisions to know what to ship.
text_ko: 대부분의 팀은 더 빨리 움직일 수 있어요. 그런데 더 빨라지는 게 무슨 소용일까요? 매일 쓰레기를 더 빠르게 출시(ship)할 수도 있어요. 뭘 출시할지 알려면 전략(strategy)과 정말 현명한 판단이 필요해요.
text_zh: 大部分团队都能提速，但是提速是为了什么呢？我们完全可以每天更快地出垃圾产品。关键是要有战略眼光，做明智的决策，知道该推出什么产品。
text_es: La mayoría de los equipos pueden ir más rápido. ¿Pero más rápido para qué? Podemos lanzar basura más rápido todos los días. Lo que necesitamos es estrategia y decisiones realmente inteligentes para saber qué vale la pena sacar al mercado.
context: Lenny asks how to know if an engineering team is moving fast enough or if they can move faster. Nicole responds that while most teams have room for improvement in speed, velocity alone isn't valuable without direction. She emphasizes that the real challenge isn't just moving faster, but ensuring teams are building the right things with proper strategic guidance.
vocabulary_highlights: ship trash

speaker: Nicole Forsgren
text: We can't just put in a command and guess something back and accept it. We really need to evaluate it. Are we seeing hallucinations? What's the reliability? Does it meet the style that we would typically write?
text_ko: 명령을 입력해서 AI가 그냥 대충 추측해 내놓은 답을 그대로 받아들일 수는 없어요. 반드시 검증해봐야 해요. 환각(hallucination)이 있는 건 아닌가요? 신뢰성은 어느 정도인가요? 우리가 평소 쓰는 문체에 맞나요?
text_zh: 我们不能就这么输个指令，然后AI随便给个回复我们就接受了。真的需要好好评估一下——有没有出现幻觉(hallucination)？可靠性怎么样？风格符不符合我们平时的写作习惯？
text_es: No podemos simplemente meter un comando y aceptar cualquier cosa que nos devuelva. De verdad necesitamos evaluarlo bien. ¿Estamos viendo alucinaciones (hallucinations)? ¿Qué tan confiable es? ¿Cumple con el estilo que normalmente manejamos nosotros?
context: Lenny discusses how one of the biggest issues with AI will be learning how much to trust the code it generates. Nicole explains that unlike traditional code compilation where you get clear feedback, LLMs are non-deterministic and require careful evaluation. She emphasizes the need to check for AI hallucinations, reliability issues, and whether the generated code meets the team's coding standards before accepting it.
vocabulary_highlights: put in a command and guess something back

speaker: Nicole Forsgren
text: There's some real opportunity there to not just rethink workflows, but rethink how we structure our days and how we structure our work. Now, we can also make a 45-minute work block useful because getting into the flow is actually kind of handed off, at least, in part to the machine or the machine can help us get back into the flow by, reminding us of context and generating diagrams of the system.
text_ko: 단순히 워크플로(workflows)를 다시 생각하는 수준이 아니라, 하루를 어떻게 짜고 업무를 어떻게 구성할지 자체를 재구성할 수 있는 진짜 기회가 있어요. 그리고 45분짜리 작업 단위도 쓸모 있게 만들 수 있어요. 플로우(flow)에 들어가는 건 적어도 일부는 기계(예: AI)가 맡아줄 수 있고, 기계가 맥락을 상기시켜주거나 시스템 다이어그램(system diagrams)을 만들어줘서 다시 플로우로 돌아가게 도와줄 수 있으니까요.
text_zh: 这里真的有很大机会，不只是重新考虑工作流程，而是重新思考我们怎么安排一天的时间，怎么组织工作。现在我们也能让45分钟的工作时间块变得很有用，因为进入心流状态(flow state)这件事其实可以部分交给机器来处理，或者说机器可以帮我们重新进入状态——比如提醒我们上下文，生成系统图表什么的。
text_es: Ahí hay una oportunidad real de no solo repensar los flujos de trabajo (workflows), sino también repensar cómo estructuramos nuestros días y cómo organizamos nuestro trabajo. Ahora también podemos hacer que un bloque de 45 minutos de trabajo sea útil porque entrar en el flujo (flow) se puede delegar, al menos en parte, a la máquina, o la máquina nos puede ayudar a recuperar ese flujo recordándonos el contexto y generando diagramas del sistema.
context: Lenny and Nicole are discussing how AI is changing the nature of engineering work, with more time spent reviewing code versus writing it. Nicole explains that this shift presents an opportunity to restructure how developers organize their workdays. She references research showing humans can only do about four hours of deep work daily, but suggests AI tools might make shorter work blocks more productive by helping developers get into flow states faster.
vocabulary_highlights: handed off, getting into the flow, work block

speaker: Nicole Forsgren
text: Honestly, I think the best thing you can do is go talk to people and listen. I love that the audience of this podcast is primarily PMs because they tend to be really good at this. And I would say start with listening and not with tools and automation.
text_ko: 솔직히 말하면, 가장 좋은 건 사람들을 직접 만나서 얘기하고 귀 기울이는 거예요. 이 팟캐스트 청중이 주로 프로덕트 매니저(PM)분들이라는 게 마음에 들어요 — 보통 이걸 잘하거든요. 그리고 저는 도구나 자동화부터 시작하지 말고 일단 듣는 것부터 시작하라고 권해요.
text_zh: 说实话，我觉得最好的办法就是去跟人聊，多听听。我特别喜欢这个播客的听众主要都是PM，因为他们在这方面通常很在行。我建议先从倾听开始，别一上来就想着用什么工具和自动化。
text_es: La verdad, creo que lo mejor que puedes hacer es ir a hablar con la gente y escuchar. Me encanta que la audiencia de este podcast sean principalmente PMs porque suelen ser muy buenos en esto. Y yo diría que empieces por escuchar, no por las herramientas y la automatización.
context: Lenny asks Nicole for one practical thing that engineering or product teams can do immediately to improve their developer experience and get more done. Nicole emphasizes that the most effective starting point isn't implementing new tools or automation, but rather conducting a listening tour with developers to understand their actual pain points and friction areas in their daily work.
topics: Communication Skills, Leadership & Management, Coaching & Development

speaker: Nicole Forsgren
text: Most teams can move faster, right? Also, given what we know about cognitive load, not all speed gains are necessarily good. Or the upside is going to be kind of limited once you hit kind of a certain point, and most people are not even near that point.
text_ko: 대부분 팀은 더 빨리 움직일 수 있어요, 그렇죠? 또 인지 부하(cognitive load)에 대해 우리가 아는 걸 감안하면, 속도를 올린다고 해서 다 좋은 건 아니에요. 어떤 한계점에 이르면 얻을 수 있는 이득이 제한될 텐데, 대부분 사람들은 그 지점에조차 못 미쳐요.
text_zh: 大部分团队都能提速，对吧？不过从认知负荷(cognitive load)的角度来看，提速也不见得都是好事。到了某个节点之后，收益其实就很有限了，而且大多数人连那个节点都还没碰到呢。
text_es: La mayoría de los equipos pueden ir más rápido, ¿no? Pero también, con lo que sabemos sobre la carga cognitiva (cognitive load), no todas las mejoras de velocidad son necesariamente buenas. O sea, los beneficios van a ser medio limitados una vez que llegas a cierto punto, y la mayoría de la gente ni siquiera está cerca de ese punto.
context: Lenny asks Nicole the challenging question that most founders think about: how to know if an engineering team is moving fast enough or could move faster. Nicole explains that while most teams have room for improvement, there are diminishing returns to speed gains due to cognitive load limitations. However, she notes that most teams haven't reached the point where these limitations become a concern.
vocabulary_highlights: cognitive load, upside is going to be kind of limited, hit kind of a certain point

speaker: Nicole Forsgren
text: Starting with what is your problem or what is your goal? I would say this is a bigger challenge than most people recognize or realize. 80% of the folks that I work with, this is their biggest problem. Even at executive levels, teams will have gone off for several months, and they're tackling something, and they'll come back with uncertainty, and they'll say like, "Well, you told me to improve developer experience."
text_ko: 무엇이 문제인지, 목표가 무엇인지부터 시작해 보세요. 이건 대부분 사람들이 인식하는 것보다 훨씬 더 큰 도전이에요. 제가 함께 일하는 분들 중 80%에게 이게 가장 큰 문제예요. 임원급에서도 팀들이 몇 달 동안 그 과제를 해오다가 불확실한 상태로 돌아와서 "그러니까 개발자 경험(developer experience)을 개선하라고 하신 거죠"라고 말하곤 해요.
text_zh: 先搞清楚你要解决什么问题，或者你的目标是什么？我觉得这比大多数人想象的要难得多。我合作过的人里面，80%最大的问题就是这个。就算是高管层面，团队可能忙活了好几个月，在那儿死磕某个事情，结果回来还是一头雾水，然后跟你说："你之前不是让我提升开发者体验(developer experience)吗。"
text_es: Empezar por "¿cuál es tu problema?" o "¿cuál es tu objetivo?" Yo diría que esto es un reto mucho más grande de lo que la mayoría de la gente se da cuenta. El 80% de las personas con las que trabajo, este es su mayor problema. Incluso a nivel ejecutivo, los equipos pueden estar trabajando durante varios meses en algo, y regresan con dudas, y te dicen algo como: "Bueno, me dijiste que mejorara la experiencia del desarrollador (developer experience)."
context: Nicole is discussing one of the most fundamental challenges in developer productivity work. She emphasizes that the majority of teams she works with struggle with clearly defining their objectives before starting improvement initiatives. Teams often spend months working on vague directives like "improve developer experience" without having a clear understanding of what specific aspect they should focus on, leading to wasted effort and confusion.
vocabulary_highlights: gone off for several months, tackling something, come back with uncertainty

speaker: Nicole Forsgren
text: I'm like, "Okay, what do you mean by this? Are you talking about inner and outer loop? Are you talking about friction? Are you talking about culture? But if you're talking about culture, this is totally different than if you're talking about friction in toolchains. If you're on different pages, you're heading in completely different directions."
text_ko: 저는 "그게 무슨 뜻이에요? 내부 루프와 외부 루프(inner and outer loop)를 말하는 건가요? 마찰(friction)을 말하는 건가요? 문화(culture)를 말하는 건가요?"라고 했어요. 근데 문화 얘기라면 도구 체인(toolchains)의 마찰 얘기랑은 완전히 달라요. 서로 같은 생각을 하고 있지 않으면 완전히 다른 방향으로 가고 있어요.
text_zh: 我就说，"等等，你这话是什么意思？你说的是内循环外循环(inner and outer loop)？还是说摩擦力(friction)？还是在讲企业文化？但如果你讲的是文化，那跟工具链摩擦(friction in toolchains)完全是两码事啊。大家想法不在一个频道上，那方向肯定就南辕北辙了。"
text_es: "Yo les digo, 'A ver, ¿qué quieren decir exactamente con eso? ¿Están hablando del bucle interno y externo (inner and outer loop)? ¿Se refieren a fricción? ¿O están hablando de cultura? Pero si se trata de cultura, eso es algo completamente distinto a si hablamos de fricción en las cadenas de herramientas (toolchains). Si no están en la misma página, van a terminar yendo cada uno por su lado.'"
context: Nicole continues explaining why clear problem definition is crucial. She illustrates how "developer experience" can mean vastly different things - from technical toolchain issues to cultural problems - and teams need to be specific about which aspect they're addressing. Without this clarity, different team members may work toward completely different goals, making their efforts ineffective.
vocabulary_highlights: inner and outer loop, on different pages, heading in completely different directions

speaker: Nicole Forsgren
text: So I started as a software engineer at IBM. I was writing software for large enterprise systems, which meant I ended up running them. So I was also a CIS admin. I was racking the stacking. I was running these really, really large labs, and then I kind of stumbled into this seven-day march for several years, and I was like, "There has to be a better way."
text_ko: IBM에서 소프트웨어 엔지니어(software engineer)로 일을 시작했어요. 대규모 엔터프라이즈 시스템(enterprise systems)용 소프트웨어를 개발했는데, 결국 그 시스템들을 직접 운영하게 되더라고요. 그래서 CIS 관리자(CIS admin) 역할도 했고, 서버를 랙에 장착하고 케이블 연결하는 랙킹과 스태킹(racking and stacking) 같은 일도 했어요. 진짜 엄청나게 큰 랩(lab)들을 운영했는데, 몇 년 동안 주 7일 쉬지 못하는 7일 행군(seven-day march)을 겪으면서 '이대로 계속할 순 없다, 분명 더 나은 방법이 있을 거야'라고 생각했어요.
text_zh: 我最开始在IBM做软件工程师，给那些大型企业系统写代码，结果就是我还得负责运维这些系统。所以我同时还是个系统管理员，要搭机架、做部署什么的。我管理着那些超大规模的实验室，然后有好几年我就陷入了那种七天连轴转的状态，我就想："肯定有更好的办法啊。"
text_es: Empecé como ingeniero de software en IBM. Estaba desarrollando software para sistemas empresariales grandes, lo que significaba que también tenía que operarlos. Así que también hacía de administrador de sistemas. Estaba armando los racks, apilando servidores. Manejaba laboratorios enormes, y después como que caí en esta marcha de siete días que duró varios años, y yo ahí pensando: "Tiene que haber una manera mejor de hacer esto."
context: Nicole describes her early career background when Lenny asks about her unique journey. She explains how she started as a software engineer at IBM working on enterprise systems, which naturally led her to also become a system administrator managing large computing environments. The "seven-day march" refers to the grueling, unsustainable work pace that was common in traditional enterprise IT operations.
vocabulary_highlights: racking the stacking, stumbled into, seven-day march

speaker: Nicole Forsgren
text: And the joke there when we met with Gartner, they were like, "Your superpower here was that you tricked people into strategy," which was not only how do I benchmark? That was kind of our top-of-the-funnel. Everyone wants to know how they compare. But the important thing is what should you do next? What's the most important next step?
text_ko: Gartner랑 만났을 때 웃긴 얘기가 있었는데요, 걔네들이 "여기서 너희의 슈퍼파워는 사람들을 전략으로 끌어들인 거였어"라고 하더라고요. 단순히 "우리는 어떻게 벤치마크(benchmark)하죠?"라는 질문만 받은 게 아니라, 그게 일종의 퍼널 상단(top-of-the-funnel)이었어요. 다들 자기들이 어디에 있는지 비교해 보길 원하잖아요. 그런데 중요한 건 그다음에 뭘 해야 하느냐예요. 다음에 가장 중요한 단계가 뭔가요?
text_zh: 有个笑话，我们跟高德纳(Gartner)开会的时候，他们说："你们的超能力就是把大家套路进了战略规划里。"不光是让人做基准测试(benchmark)那么简单，这其实是我们的引流手段(top-of-the-funnel)。每个人都想知道自己跟别人比怎么样。但关键是接下来该怎么办？下一步最重要的是什么？
text_es: Y lo gracioso es que cuando nos reunimos with Gartner, nos dijeron: "Su superpoder aquí fue que engañaron a la gente para que hiciera estrategia", que no era solo cómo me comparo con otros. Eso era como nuestro gancho inicial (top-of-the-funnel). Todo el mundo quiere saber cómo se posiciona frente a la competencia. Pero lo importante es ¿qué deberías hacer después? ¿Cuál es el siguiente paso más importante?
context: Nicole is describing feedback she received about DORA's business approach from Gartner analysts. She explains how DORA attracted customers initially through benchmarking services - allowing companies to compare their performance against industry standards - but the real value was in providing strategic guidance on improvement priorities. This created a pathway from measurement to actionable strategy.
vocabulary_highlights: tricked people into strategy, top-of-the-funnel

speaker: Nicole Forsgren
text: And when I first started ITIL and ITSM, right, the old school kind of change management processes, the common knowledge was that you had to have at least a two-week wait for change approvals in order to get that stability. Turns out that's not right. It was just kind of an old wives' tale, right.
text_ko: 제가 ITIL과 ITSM(IT Service Management)을 처음 시작했을 때요, 예전식 변경 관리 프로세스(change management processes) 쪽에서는 안정성을 위해 변경 승인(change approvals)을 받기까지 최소 2주는 기다려야 한다고들 했어요. 그런데 알고 보니 그게 사실이 아니었어요. 그냥 오래된 속설에 불과했더라고요.
text_zh: 我刚开始接触ITIL和ITSM(IT服务管理)的时候，那种老式的变更管理流程，大家都认为变更审批至少要等两个星期才能保证系统稳定性。结果发现这完全是错的，就是一个老掉牙的说法而已。
text_es: Y cuando empecé con ITIL e ITSM, ¿verdad?, esos procesos de gestión de cambios de la vieja escuela, lo que todo el mundo daba por hecho era que tenías que esperar como mínimo dos semanas para que te aprobaran los cambios si querías tener estabilidad. Resulta que eso no era cierto. Era más bien un mito, ¿no?
context: Nicole is explaining how traditional IT service management approaches were based on incorrect assumptions. ITIL (Information Technology Infrastructure Library) and ITSM (IT Service Management) were established frameworks that required lengthy approval processes for any system changes, based on the belief that waiting would improve stability. Her research proved this conventional wisdom was actually counterproductive.
vocabulary_highlights: old wives' tale

speaker: Nicole Forsgren
text: We want to implement good technical practices like automated testing, good architectural practices so that when you move fast, you are also more stable, right. We want to be thinking about improving the developer experience so that when we are faster, we are also saving time.
text_ko: 우리는 자동화된 테스트(automated testing) 같은 좋은 기술 관행과 좋은 아키텍처 관행(architectural practices)을 도입해서, 속도를 내더라도 더 안정적일 수 있게 하고 싶어요. 또 개발자 경험(developer experience)을 개선하는 데 계속 신경 써서, 빨라질수록 시간도 절약되게 하고 싶어요.
text_zh: 我们想要落地一些好的技术实践，比如自动化测试(automated testing)，还有好的架构实践，这样你跑得快的同时，系统也更稳定，对吧。我们还要考虑提升开发者体验(developer experience)，这样我们提速的同时，也能节省时间。
text_es: Queremos implementar buenas prácticas técnicas como las pruebas automatizadas (automated testing), buenas prácticas de arquitectura para que cuando te muevas rápido, también tengas más estabilidad, ¿no? Queremos pensar en mejorar la experiencia del desarrollador (developer experience) para que cuando seamos más rápidos, también estemos ahorrando tiempo.
context: Nicole is explaining the core principle behind effective DevOps practices. Rather than simply removing all safety measures to move faster, the goal is to implement proper technical foundations like automated testing and good system architecture. This allows teams to achieve both speed and stability simultaneously, while also improving the overall developer experience through better tooling and processes.

speaker: Nicole Forsgren
text: Most people only think about this from the speed standpoint, which means when you move faster, you are more stable, which means you're pushing smaller changes more often, right. Because if you're pushing all the time, it's going to be very, very small changes, which means you have a smaller blast radius, which means when you push, you have an error in production. It's going to be easier to debug, right.
text_ko: 대부분 사람들은 이걸 속도 관점(speed standpoint)에서만 바라봐요. 빨리 움직이면 더 안정적이라는 건데, 그건 다시 말해 더 작은 변경을 더 자주 배포(deploy)한다는 뜻이에요. 계속 배포하면 변경 폭이 아주 작아져서 영향 범위(blast radius)가 줄고, 그래서 프로덕션(production)에서 에러가 나더라도 디버깅(debug)이 훨씬 쉬워요.
text_zh: 大部分人只从速度这个角度来看这个问题，就是说你动作越快，其实越稳定，因为你会更频繁地推送一些小的改动，对吧。因为如果你一直在推送的话，每次的改动都会很小很小，这样你的影响范围(blast radius)就比较小，所以当你推送的时候，生产环境出了问题，调试起来就容易多了，对吧。
text_es: La mayoría de la gente solo piensa en esto desde el punto de vista de la velocidad, o sea que cuando te mueves más rápido, eres más estable, lo que significa que estás subiendo cambios más pequeños y más seguido, ¿no? Porque si estás subiendo todo el tiempo, van a ser cambios muy, muy pequeños, lo que significa que tienes un radio de impacto (blast radius) menor, entonces cuando subes algo y tienes un error en producción, va a ser mucho más fácil hacer el debug, ¿me explico?
context: Nicole is explaining one of her key research findings about the relationship between deployment frequency and system stability. She's describing how the DORA metrics revealed that speed and stability move together - teams that deploy more frequently actually have more stable systems. This counterintuitive finding occurs because frequent deployments involve smaller changes that are easier to debug when problems arise.
vocabulary_highlights: blast radius

speaker: Nikhyl Singhal
speaker_expertise: Consumer Products, Team Building, Leadership Development
text: I think that there are probably two quick things that I would say you have to get bravely thoughtful about as you enter into this journey. One is, your challenge is going to be to share the steering wheel with the person or the set of people you are managing. And I think that there's this three modes that people have in their head. They're like, "Oh, management is divide and conquering. You go there, I go there, we meet up." Or they'll say it's like riding a bike, or teaching to ride a bike, I should say. Someone starts out on the bicycle, I hold your hand, I let go, and then I hope that you fly. I think it's more like the sidecar on the motorcycle, where person's driving the motorcycle and I'm on the sidecar and whether I like it or not, I'm attached, but I have this relatively specific role of giving counsel.
text_ko: 이 여정을 시작할 때 용기 있게 생각해봐야 할 빠른 포인트가 아마 두 가지 정도 있다고 생각해요. 하나는, 당신이 직면할 과제가 관리하는 사람들(혹은 특정 개인)과 운전대를 함께 잡는 법을 배우는 거예요. 사람들은 보통 머릿속에 세 가지 방식이 있더라고요. 어떤 사람들은 "매니지먼트는 나눠서 정복하는 거야. 너는 거기, 나는 여기, 나중에 만나서 확인하자"라고 생각해요. 또 어떤 사람들은 경영을 자전거 타기, 그러니까 자전거 타는 법을 가르치는 것에 비유해요. 누군가 자전거를 타기 시작하면 내가 손을 잡아주다가 놓아주고, 그러면 네가 잘해내길 바라죠. 저는 오히려 오토바이의 사이드카(sidecar)에 더 가깝다고 봐요. 누군가는 오토바이를 운전하고 저는 사이드카에 타 있는데, 좋든 싫든 붙어 있고 제 역할은 비교적 구체적으로 조언을 해주는 거예요.
text_zh: 我觉得当你开始这个管理之旅的时候，有两个要点你必须勇敢地去深入思考。第一个就是，你面临的挑战是要学会跟你管理的人或团队分享主导权。我觉得大家脑子里对管理有三种理解模式。有人会想："哦，管理就是分工合作嘛，你干你的，我干我的，最后汇合。"或者他们会说管理像骑自行车，更准确地说是教别人骑车。有人刚开始骑车，我扶着你，然后松手，希望你能自己骑走。但我觉得管理更像摩托车旁边的边斗，那个人在开摩托车，我坐在边斗里，不管我愿不愿意，我都是连着的，但我有个相对明确的角色，就是给建议当参谋。
text_es: Creo que hay probablemente dos cosas rápidas que te diría que tienes que pensar de manera valiente y reflexiva cuando te metes en este viaje. Una es que tu reto va a ser compartir el volante con la persona o el grupo de personas que estás manejando. Y creo que la gente tiene como tres modelos en la cabeza. Piensan, "Ay, manejar gente es divide y vencerás. Tú te vas por allá, yo me voy por acá, y nos encontramos después." O dicen que es como andar en bicicleta, o mejor dicho, enseñar a andar en bicicleta. Alguien se sube a la bici, yo te agarro la mano, te suelto, y luego espero que vueles solo. Yo creo que es más como el sidecar de la motocicleta, donde una persona maneja la moto y yo voy en el sidecar y me guste o no, estoy pegado, pero tengo este rol bastante específico de dar consejos.
context: Lenny asks about common pitfalls for first-time managers and what they should focus on when entering management. Nikhyl explains that new managers need to learn how to share responsibility rather than either completely delegating (divide and conquer) or temporarily taking control then handing off (teaching to ride a bike). Instead, he advocates for a collaborative approach where the manager stays connected like a motorcycle sidecar - always present to provide counsel while the other person drives.
vocabulary_highlights: get bravely thoughtful about, divide and conquering, sidecar on the motorcycle, giving counsel

speaker: Nikhyl Singhal
speaker_expertise: Consumer Products, Team Building, Leadership Development
text: And then I think that the second miss that people tend to have is they tend to, because they have power, by the way, organizational power, not because they've earned that power, they start managing whatever they define that to be. And what I find is that you're more like the vampire knocking on the door of someone. You have to be invited in. You just can't walk through the threshold. And I think that no matter how senior the person that is the manager, you have to earn the right to be the person's manager.
text_ko: 두 번째로 사람들이 놓치는 게 하나 있어요. 보통 조직적 권력(organizational power)을 갖고 있다고—그리고 그 권력을 정당하게 얻은 게 아닌 경우가 많은데요—그걸로 자기가 관리하겠다고 정의한 걸 관리하려 들죠. 제가 보기엔 매니저(manager)는 초인종을 누르는 흡혈귀(vampire) 같은 거예요. 초대받아 들어가야지, 그냥 문턱을 넘어 들어갈 수는 없어요. 아무리 직급이 높더라도 누군가의 관리자가 될 권리는 스스로 얻어야 해요.
text_zh: 我觉得大家容易犯的第二个错误就是，他们因为手里有权力——注意啊，是组织给的权力，不是自己挣来的——就开始管这管那的。我发现这就像吸血鬼敲门一样，你得被邀请进去才行，不能硬闯。我觉得不管这个管理者职位多高，你都得先赢得下属的认可，让人家心甘情愿接受你当他们的领导。
text_es: Y luego creo que el segundo error que comete la gente es que, como tienen poder —poder organizacional, ojo, no porque se hayan ganado ese poder— empiezan a gestionar lo que ellos creen que es gestionar. Y lo que me doy cuenta es que eres más como el vampiro que toca a la puerta de alguien. Tienes que ser invitado a pasar. No puedes simplemente cruzar el umbral así nomás. Y creo que no importa qué tan senior sea la persona que es el jefe, tienes que ganarte el derecho a ser el manager de esa persona.
context: Nikhyl continues explaining common mistakes new managers make when transitioning to management roles. He describes how organizational hierarchy gives managers formal authority, but effective management requires earning trust and permission from team members. Using a vampire metaphor, he explains that just as vampires must be invited into homes, managers must be invited into their team members' work and challenges rather than forcing their involvement based solely on title or position.
vocabulary_highlights: the vampire knocking on the door, walk through the threshold, earn the right to be

speaker: Nikhyl Singhal
speaker_expertise: Consumer Products, Team Building, Leadership Development
text: I think the IC track is one of the best things that's going to happen for people career. But to your point, those tracks, from a promotion and from a industry, how we perceive it, they're not in cement yet. They're tender. You wait six months, you wait nine months, they'll become very, very strong and solid. And I think then, we'll be able to lean very hard into them as a real promising crack for builders.
text_ko: IC 트랙(IC track)은 사람들의 커리어에 있어 가장 좋은 변화 중 하나가 될 거라고 생각해요. 하지만 말씀하신 것처럼 승진이나 업계 인식 측면에서는 그 트랙들이 아직 확정된 게 아니고 정형화되지 않았어요. 6개월, 9개월 정도 지나면 훨씬 더 강하고 견고해질 거예요. 그때가 되면 저희도 그 트랙을 빌더들(builders)에게 정말 유망한 돌파구로 삼아 적극적으로 활용할 수 있을 것 같아요.
text_zh: 我觉得IC这条职业路径(IC track)对大家的职业发展来说绝对是个好事儿。但就像你说的，这些路径在升职和行业认知方面，现在还没完全成型，还比较脆弱。你再等个半年、九个月的，它们就会变得非常扎实稳固了。到那时候，我们就能真正把它当作技术人员很有前景的发展通道来大力推广了。
text_es: Creo que la carrera de IC (individual contributor) va a ser una de las mejores cosas que le puede pasar a la gente profesionalmente. Pero como dices, estas carreras, en cuanto a promociones y cómo las ve la industria, todavía no están grabadas en piedra. Están tiernas aún. Esperas seis meses, esperas nueve meses, y se van a volver muy, muy sólidas. Y creo que entonces sí vamos a poder apostarle fuerte como una opción muy prometedora para los desarrolladores.
context: Lenny asks about the senior individual contributor (IC) path as an alternative to management for product managers. Nikhyl believes the IC track will become increasingly valuable as companies reduce management layers and focus on core building skills. He explains that while these career paths are currently unstable ('tender'), they will solidify over time and become legitimate options for people who want to focus on building rather than managing teams.
vocabulary_highlights: not in cement yet, they're tender, lean very hard into them, promising crack for builders

speaker: Nikhyl Singhal
speaker_expertise: Consumer Products, Team Building, Leadership Development
text: This came from my notes as I was talking to a therapist on this. They talked about the shadows of superpowers. And I thought it was an incredibly powerful phrase that everyone focuses on your superpowers, but no one ever thinks about what shadows they create. Shadows of superpowers to me is the story of a lot of executives. There's an adage that's thrown around, which is, what gets you there isn't what got you here. It's sort of the tools that have made you successful today, you need to almost rebuild or relearn to get to the next phase.
text_ko: 이건 제가 치료사와 얘기하다가 메모해둔 내용이에요. 치료사가 '슈퍼파워의 그림자(shadows of superpowers)'에 대해 얘기해줬는데, 저는 그 표현이 정말 강력하다고 느꼈어요. 사람들은 모두 강점이나 능력(슈퍼파워)만 보는데, 그로 인해 생기는 그림자는 아무도 잘 생각하지 않잖아요. '슈퍼파워의 그림자'는 제게 많은 임원들의 이야기 같아요. 그리고 흔히들 하는 말이 하나 있는데, '오늘 당신을 여기까지 데려다 준 게 내일도 당신을 데려다주진 않는다'—영어로는 'what gets you there isn't what got you here'예요. 지금까지 성공하게 해준 도구나 방식은 다음 단계로 가려면 거의 다시 설계하거나 다시 배워야 하는 경우가 많아요.
text_zh: 这个想法来自我和治疗师聊天时记下的笔记。他们提到了"超能力的阴影面"这个概念，我觉得特别有道理——大家都盯着你的超能力看，但从来没人想过这些能力会产生什么阴影。对我来说，超能力的阴影面就是很多高管的真实写照。有句老话说得好："让你走到这里的东西，未必能让你走得更远。"就是说，今天让你成功的那些招数，想要进入下一个阶段的话，你几乎得重新来过，重新学。
text_es: Esto salió de mis notas cuando estaba hablando con un terapeuta sobre el tema. Me habló de las sombras de los superpoderes. Y me pareció una frase increíblemente poderosa - que todo el mundo se enfoca en tus superpoderes, pero nadie piensa en qué sombras crean. Para mí, las sombras de los superpoderes es la historia de muchos ejecutivos. Hay un dicho que se escucha mucho: "lo que te trajo hasta aquí no es lo que te va a llevar allá". Es como que las herramientas que te han hecho exitoso hoy, casi que tienes que reconstruirlas o reaprender para llegar a la siguiente fase.
context: Lenny asks about senior leaders who have development areas hidden behind their strengths. Nikhyl introduces the concept of 'shadows of superpowers' - the idea that every strength creates corresponding blind spots or weaknesses. He explains that as people advance in their careers, the very skills that made them successful can become obstacles at higher levels, requiring them to rebuild their approach rather than rely on what worked before.
vocabulary_highlights: shadows of superpowers, there's an adage that's thrown around, rebuild or relearn
topics: Leadership & Management, Career Development, Coaching & Development

speaker: Nikhyl Singhal
speaker_expertise: Consumer Products, Team Building, Leadership Development
text: The way that they motivated the dogs was they had these fake rabbits. These tails would go around faster than the dogs, which would then motivate the dogs to go around in circles. And what was interesting is the moment that the dogs, if they accidentally touched the rabbit, they would never run again because there was like, "Well, what's next? I've achieved what I was looking for." So I think this happens a ton, it's like your listeners are spending time focused on like, "Well, one day I will be X. I will be that vice president. I will have more money. I will have built something. I will have started a company." But they don't think about what happens next.
text_ko: 개들을 자극한 방식은 가짜 토끼를 둔 거예요. 그 토끼 꼬리가 개들보다 더 빨리 돌아가니까 개들이 빙글빙글 돌게 만드는 거죠. 근데 흥미로운 건, 만약 개가 우연히라도 그 토끼를 건드리면 다시는 달리지 않는다는 거예요. 왜냐하면 “됐네, 내가 원하던 걸 이뤘어. 다음은 뭐지?”라고 생각하기 때문이에요. 이건 사람들이 많이 하는 실수랑 똑같아요. 듣고 있는 사람들은 “언젠가 나는 X가 될 거야. 부사장(vice president)이 될 거야. 돈을 더 벌 거야. 뭔가를 만들어낼 거야. 회사를 세울 거야.”라고 말은 하지만, 그 다음엔 무슨 일이 벌어질지에 대해서는 생각을 안 해요.
text_zh: 他们训练狗的方式是这样的，用假兔子来逗狗跑。这些假兔子跑得比狗快，狗就会被带动着一圈圈地追。有意思的是，一旦狗碰到了兔子，它们就再也不跑了，因为会想"然后呢？我已经得到想要的了。"我觉得这种情况特别常见，就像你的听众把时间都花在想"总有一天我要成为某某，我要当上VP，我要赚更多钱，我要做成什么事，我要创业"，但他们从来不想接下来会怎样。
text_es: La forma en que motivaban a los perros era con estos conejos falsos. Estas colas daban vueltas más rápido que los perros, lo que hacía que los perros corrieran en círculos tratando de alcanzarlos. Y lo interesante es que en el momento en que los perros, si por casualidad tocaban el conejo, nunca más volvían a correr porque era como "¿Y ahora qué? Ya logré lo que buscaba." Entonces creo que esto pasa muchísimo, es como que tus oyentes se la pasan enfocados en "Bueno, algún día voy a ser X. Voy a ser ese vicepresidente. Voy a tener más dinero. Voy a haber construido algo. Voy a haber arrancado una empresa." Pero no piensan en qué pasa después.
context: Nikhyl opens the podcast by discussing how successful people often experience emptiness after achieving their goals. He uses a metaphor from greyhound dog racing where dogs chase mechanical rabbits - if they ever catch the rabbit, they lose motivation to run again. He explains that many professionals focus intensely on reaching specific career milestones (becoming VP, making money, starting companies) without considering what meaningful goals will drive them after they succeed.
vocabulary_highlights: fake rabbits, go around in circles, accidentally touched, what happens next

speaker: Nikhyl Singhal
speaker_expertise: Consumer Products, Team Building, Leadership Development
text: My fear is, from a career point of view, so many tech professionals are in these organizations or joining these organizations with the expectation that they'll make money on their equity, that they'll continue to do fine. And my sense is we're going to see, even in the second half of this year, lots of boards pulling back, taking their capital back, companies essentially saying, "Hey, we're capitalized. We're a scaled ocean liner, and now we need to go find product market fit." But doing that with 300 people and expectations of hitting a multi-billion dollar valuation just isn't going to happen.
text_ko: 제 걱정은 경력 관점에서 많은 테크 전문가들이 이 조직들에 있거나 합류할 때 지분(equity)으로 돈을 벌 거라고 기대해서 앞으로도 괜찮을 거라고 생각한다는 거예요. 그런데 제 느낌에는 올해 하반기에도 많은 이사회(boards)들이 한발 물러서서 투자금을 회수하고, 회사들은 사실상 "우린 자금이 확보됐어요(capitalized). 우리는 규모가 큰 배인데 이제 제품-시장 적합성(product-market fit)을 찾아야 해요"라고 말할 것 같아요. 그런데 직원이 300명이나 되고 수십억 달러 밸류에이션(valuation)을 기대하는 상황에서 그렇게 하는 건 현실적으로 불가능할 거예요.
text_zh: 我担心的是，从职业发展角度来看，现在有太多技术人员在这些公司里，或者正在加入这些公司，他们都指望着靠股权赚钱，觉得自己会一直过得不错。但我感觉，甚至在今年下半年，我们就会看到很多董事会开始收手，把资金撤回去，公司基本上会说："嘿，我们资金到位了，我们现在是一艘大型远洋轮船，接下来需要去找产品市场契合点(product market fit)。"但是带着300个人，还指望着达到几十亿美元的估值，这根本不现实。
text_es: Mi preocupación es que, desde el punto de vista profesional, muchos profesionales de tecnología están en estas empresas o se están uniendo con la expectativa de que van a ganar dinero con sus acciones, de que todo va a seguir bien.
