Y mi impresión es que vamos a ver, incluso en la segunda mitad de este año, muchas juntas directivas echándose para atrás, retirando su capital, empresas que básicamente van a decir: "Oye, ya estamos capitalizados. Somos un transatlántico gigante, y ahora necesitamos encontrar el ajuste producto-mercado (product market fit)". Pero hacer eso con 300 personas y expectativas de alcanzar una valuación de miles de millones de dólares simplemente no va a pasar.
context: Lenny asks Nikhyl to explain what he means by 'ex-growth companies' and why they're problematic for product managers. Nikhyl describes companies that raised significant funding during the hypergrowth era but haven't achieved sustainable growth or product-market fit. These companies are now 'scaled ocean liners' - large organizations with high valuations that still need to find their core product success, which creates an impossible situation for employees expecting equity value.
vocabulary_highlights: pulling back, scaled ocean liner, hitting a multi-billion dollar valuation, just isn't going to happen
topics: Career Development, Starting a Company, Strategy & Planning

speaker: Nikita Bier
text: I looked on the App Store and the number one app in the United States was an app called Sarahah, but the entire app was in Arabic. The number one app in the United States was in Arabic. And that was one of the most strongest signal that you could ever have that people want something.
text_ko: 앱스토어를 보니까 미국에서 1위인 앱이 'Sarahah'였는데, 앱 전체가 아랍어로 되어 있었어요. 미국 1위 앱이 아랍어였다는 건 사람들이 뭔가를 원한다는 가장 강력한 신호 중 하나였어요.
text_zh: 我当时看了一下应用商店(App Store)，美国排名第一的应用竟然是一个叫Sarahah的软件，但整个应用界面全是阿拉伯语。你想想，美国市场排第一的应用居然是阿拉伯语的！这简直是最强烈的市场信号了，说明用户对这类产品的需求有多迫切。
text_es: Revisé la App Store y la aplicación número uno en Estados Unidos era una app que se llamaba Sarahah, pero toda la aplicación estaba en árabe. La app número uno en Estados Unidos estaba en árabe. Y esa fue una de las señales más claras que puedes tener de que la gente realmente quiere algo.
context: Lenny asks Nikita what insight helped him come up with tbh as a big idea worth pursuing. Nikita explains how he discovered that teens were playing a trend called TBH on Snapchat for anonymous feedback, and when researching the market, he found that Sarahah (an anonymous messaging app entirely in Arabic) was the number one app in the US App Store. This was a powerful signal of latent demand - people desperately wanted this type of anonymous communication tool even though the existing option wasn't in their language.
vocabulary_highlights: strongest signal, latent demand

speaker: Nikita Bier
text: The way you should be searching for product ideas is this concept of latent demand where people are trying to obtain a particular value and going through a very distortive process to obtain that value. If you can actually crystallize what their motivation is and build a product around and clear up what they're trying to actually do, you can have this kind of intense adoption.
text_ko: 제품 아이디어를 찾을 때는 사람들이 어떤 가치를 얻으려고 하면서 그걸 얻기 위해 비효율적이고 우회적인 과정을 밟고 있는, 즉 잠재 수요(latent demand)를 찾아야 해요. 그들의 동기를 정확히 파악해서 그걸 중심으로 제품을 만들고, 그들이 실제로 하려는 일을 명확히 해주면 폭발적인 채택(adoption)이 일어나요.
text_zh: 找产品点子的正确思路应该是这样的：挖掘潜在需求(latent demand)，就是用户想要获得某种价值，但现在的获取过程特别繁琐扭曲。如果你能准确把握他们的真实动机，围绕这个动机来做产品，把他们真正想做的事情理顺了，那用户接受度会非常高。
text_es: La forma en que deberías buscar ideas de producto es este concepto de demanda latente donde la gente está tratando de obtener un valor específico pero está pasando por un proceso súper complicado para conseguirlo. Si logras entender realmente cuál es su motivación y crear un producto alrededor de eso, y simplificar lo que están tratando de hacer en realidad, puedes tener una adopción brutal.
context: Nikita continues explaining his framework for identifying successful product opportunities. He defines latent demand as situations where people want something badly enough that they'll use suboptimal solutions to get it. When he saw people using an Arabic app for anonymous messaging in the US, it showed there was strong unmet demand for this type of product that entrepreneurs could capitalize on by building a better solution.
vocabulary_highlights: latent demand, distortive process, crystallize, intense adoption

speaker: Nikita Bier
text: The thing I didn't realize as a product manager in a large tech company is there is very little product management that you do. They're mainly just writing documents and then being the team secretary and running around getting approvals, but products live and die in the pixels. You should be designing the hierarchy, the pixels, the flows, everything. That's on you.
text_ko: 제가 대형 테크 회사에서 프로덕트 매니저(product manager)로 일할 때 몰랐던 건, 실제로는 프로덕트 매니지먼트(product management)를 거의 하지 않는다는 거예요. 대부분 문서만 쓰고 팀 비서처럼 결재 받으러 다니는 일이 많지만, 제품의 성패는 픽셀(pixels)에 달려 있어요. 계층 구조(hierarchy), 픽셀(pixels), 플로우(flows) — 그 모든 걸 디자인해야 해요. 그건 결국 프로덕트 매니저의 몫이에요.
text_zh: 我在大厂做产品经理的时候才发现，其实你根本做不了什么真正的产品管理。基本上就是写写文档，当个团队秘书，到处跑流程要批准。但是产品的成败其实就在那些细节里。页面层级、像素细节、用户流程，这些东西都得你来把控，这是你的责任。
text_es: Lo que no me daba cuenta cuando era product manager en una empresa grande de tecnología es que en realidad haces muy poco manejo de producto. Básicamente te la pasas escribiendo documentos y siendo como el secretario del equipo, corriendo de un lado a otro buscando aprobaciones, pero los productos viven y mueren en los píxeles. Tú deberías estar diseñando la jerarquía, los píxeles, los flujos (flows), todo. Eso te toca a ti.
context: Lenny asks about Nikita's experience working at Facebook after selling tbh to them. Nikita explains his disillusionment with the product manager role at large tech companies, where PMs are separated from actual product design work. He argues that for consumer products especially, success depends on the detailed design decisions - the actual pixels and user flows - which PMs at big companies often don't control directly.
vocabulary_highlights: live and die in the pixels, team secretary

speaker: Nikita Bier
text: With certainty, if you're good at your job, you can make an app grow and go viral. Over the years of building all these apps, I've accrued all these growth hacks that still nobody knows about.
text_ko: 확실히, 일을 잘하면 앱을 키워서 바이럴(viral)까지 만들 수 있어요. 수년간 여러 앱을 만들어오면서 아직 아무도 모르는 그로스 해킹 기법들(growth hacks)을 꽤 많이 모아뒀어요.
text_zh: 我敢肯定，如果你真的有两把刷子，绝对能让一个App火起来，甚至爆红。这么多年做下来，我积累了不少增长黑客(growth hack)的套路，到现在还没人知道呢。
text_es: Con toda seguridad, si eres bueno en lo tuyo, puedes hacer que una app despegue y se vuelva viral. A lo largo de los años desarrollando todas estas apps, he ido acumulando un montón de trucos de crecimiento (growth hacks) que todavía nadie conoce.
context: Lenny asks whether there's anything else that will help with building successful apps. Nikita explains his strong belief that viral growth can be engineered rather than being purely luck-based. He emphasizes that through building 15+ apps over several years, he's developed systematic approaches and techniques for making apps grow virally that go beyond what most people understand about growth.
vocabulary_highlights: with certainty, accrued, growth hacks

speaker: Nikita Bier
text: The thing that is hard to really understand for first-time founders that hit breakout success with a consumer product is how draining and how spread thin you get, because everything breaks. Everything that you built needs to be substituted almost every three days.
text_ko: 소비자용 제품(consumer product)으로 대박 성공(breakout success)을 거둔 첫 창업자들이 진짜로 이해하기 어려운 건, 얼마나 지치고 일이 여기저기 분산돼 감당하기 힘들어지는지예요. 모든 게 계속 망가져서 만든 것들을 거의 사흘마다 다시 대체해야 할 정도예요.
text_zh: 第一次创业就做出爆款消费产品的创始人很难理解的一点是，你会被榨干，精力被分散到各个地方，因为什么都会出问题。你搭建的每个系统基本上每三天就得重新来一遍。
text_es: Lo que es difícil de entender para los fundadores primerizos que pegan el golpe con un producto de consumo es lo agotador que se vuelve todo y cómo te quedas sin recursos, porque todo se rompe. Todo lo que construiste hay que cambiarlo prácticamente cada tres días.
context: Lenny asks what other lasting lessons Nikita learned from building tbh that he brings to new apps today. Nikita explains the intense operational challenges that come with viral success - when your app suddenly scales massively, all your systems break and need to be replaced constantly. This creates absolute chaos that founders need to be prepared for, requiring ruthless prioritization to keep the app running as it grows exponentially.
vocabulary_highlights: spread thin, substituted, breakout success

speaker: Nikita Bier
text: I was sleeping three hours a day for three months. It was extraordinarily difficult to do it all. Our team was also relentless though. They would come over to my house, 9:00 AM, stay until midnight and just do that seven days a week.
text_ko: 세 달 동안 하루에 세 시간밖에 못 잤어요. 모든 걸 다 해내기가 정말 힘들었어요. 그래도 우리 팀은 끝까지 포기하지 않았어요. 매일 오전 9시에 제 집에 와서 자정까지 머물면서 주 7일 내내 그렇게 일했어요.
text_zh: 那三个月我每天只睡三个小时，真的是太难熬了。不过我们团队也是拼了命的，他们早上九点就到我家，一直干到半夜，就这样一周七天不停歇。
text_es: Dormía tres horas al día durante tres meses. Era increíblemente difícil hacer todo eso. Pero nuestro equipo también era imparable. Se aparecían en mi casa a las 9 de la mañana, se quedaban hasta medianoche y así siete días a la semana, sin parar.
context: Lenny asks what it was like managing viral growth while simultaneously fighting false rumors that Gas was used for human trafficking. Nikita describes the intense physical and mental demands of scaling a viral app while dealing with crisis management. The human trafficking hoax threatened to kill the company, requiring around-the-clock effort from the entire team to combat false information spreading faster than their app itself.
vocabulary_highlights: relentless

speaker: Nikita Miller
speaker_expertise: Product Management, Team Building, Growth Strategy
text: And some folks, myself included at certain points, swung way too far on the outcomes train and forgot that output is an indicator of that. So if you have a team that's doing all of the ideation and figuring out how to make decisions quickly and getting the right documentation and setting up the right product briefs and design briefs and experiment briefs, all the things that we know go into to successful product development, that's great, but if you're also not shipping a lot of things to market quickly enough, then it just doesn't matter that much.
text_ko: 사실 어떤 사람들, 저도 가끔 그랬는데, 성과(outcomes)에만 너무 치우치다 보니 산출(output)이 그걸 보여주는 지표라는 걸 잊었어요. 그래서 팀이 아이데이션(ideation)을 하고, 빠르게 의사결정하는 방법을 찾아 문서화도 잘 해두고, 제품 브리프(product briefs), 디자인 브리프(design briefs), 실험 브리프(experiment briefs) 같은 것들까지 다 갖추고 있다면 그건 정말 좋은 일이에요. 그런데도 시장에 빨리 많이 출시(shipping)하지 못하면 그건 별로 큰 의미가 없어요.
text_zh: 有些人，包括我自己在某些时候，都太过于追求结果导向，忘记了产出其实是结果的一个体现。所以说，如果你的团队在做头脑风暴(ideation)、快速决策、整理合适的文档、制定产品简报(product briefs)、设计简报(design briefs)、实验简报(experiment briefs)等等这些我们都知道对成功的产品开发很重要的事情，这当然很好，但如果你们同时没有足够快地把很多东西推向市场，那这些其实都没什么太大意义。
text_es: Y algunas personas, yo incluido en ciertos momentos, nos fuimos demasiado al extremo con el tema de los resultados finales y se nos olvidó que lo que produces es un indicador de eso. O sea, si tienes un equipo que está haciendo toda la lluvia de ideas (ideation) y descubriendo cómo tomar decisiones rápido y consiguiendo la documentación correcta y armando los briefs de producto adecuados y los briefs de diseño y los briefs de experimentos, todas esas cosas que sabemos que van en el desarrollo exitoso de productos, eso está genial, pero si también no estás lanzando muchas cosas al mercado lo suficientemente rápido, entonces realmente no importa tanto.
context: Lenny asks Nikita about lessons she's learned about building successful teams. Nikita explains a common problem she's observed across companies where teams become too focused on outcomes (like setting goals and OKRs) while neglecting output (actual shipping and execution). She argues that while having the right goals is important, teams also need to monitor how quickly they're actually delivering products to market, as output serves as a key indicator of whether the outcomes-focused approach is working.
vocabulary_highlights: swung way too far, outcomes train, indicator of that, go into, doesn't matter that much
topics: Product Management, Leadership & Management, Strategy & Planning

speaker: Nikita Miller
speaker_expertise: Product Management, Team Building, Growth Strategy
text: The exercise that I often do is I generally have an idea of what I think the roles and responsibilities are and the expectations across these four roles, but the exercise especially with leaders in an org is to have them sit down and write them for each other. So Atlassian has some of this that they do in the form of playbooks, but it's basically I as a product leader, I'm going to write down what I think the expectations and the role and responsibilities of my engineering manager, of my designer, of my data.
text_ko: 제가 자주 하는 연습은 보통 이 네 가지 역할에 대해 제가 생각하는 역할과 책임(roles and responsibilities)과 기대치를 대략 정리해 놓는 거예요. 그런데 조직 내 리더들과 할 때는 서로 앉아서 각자 서로를 위해 그걸 직접 써보게 하는 게 핵심이에요. Atlassian도 이런 걸 플레이북(playbooks) 형태로 일부 하고 있고, 기본적으로 저는 프로덕트 리더(product leader)로서 제 엔지니어링 매니저(engineering manager), 디자이너(designer), 데이터 담당자(data)에게 기대하는 역할과 책임을 직접 적어보는 거예요.
text_zh: 我经常做的一个练习是这样的：虽然我心里大概知道这四个岗位的职责分工和期望值是什么，但我特别喜欢让团队里的领导们坐下来，互相给对方写一遍。Atlassian就有类似的做法，他们叫playbook（工作手册），基本上就是我作为产品负责人，把我认为的工程经理、设计师、数据分析师他们各自的职责和期望值都写下来。
text_es: El ejercicio que suelo hacer es que generalmente tengo una idea de cuáles creo que son los roles y responsabilidades, y las expectativas entre estos cuatro roles, pero el ejercicio, especialmente con líderes en la organización, es hacer que se sienten y los escriban el uno para el otro. Atlassian tiene algo de esto que hacen en forma de playbooks, pero básicamente es: yo, como líder de producto, voy a escribir lo que creo que son las expectativas, el rol y las responsabilidades de mi gerente de ingeniería, de mi diseñador, de mi analista de datos.
context: Lenny asks Nikita about her biggest lessons for building successful teams. Nikita describes her framework for creating clear roles and responsibilities within cross-functional product teams. She advocates for expanding the traditional product-design-engineering triad to include data scientists as a fourth member. Her approach involves having each team member write down not only their own role but also their expectations of their counterparts, then reviewing these together to create a shared agreement or 'contract' about how the team will work together.
vocabulary_highlights: sit down and write them, in the form of, write down
topics: Product Management, Leadership & Management, Communication Skills

speaker: Nikita Miller
speaker_expertise: Product Management, Team Building, Growth Strategy
text: From my experience as a product manager, it was always a blocker. Getting your hands on the data, maybe having someone to troubleshoot with if as a PM you couldn't kind of understand or figure it out yourself, it was just always a blocker. And so then you'd also then have to go and negotiate with other teams about getting someone's resources to look at this problem, so that's one.
text_ko: 프로덕트 매니저(product manager)로 일하면서 제 경험으론 그게 항상 블로커(blocker)였어요. 데이터를 직접 확보하거나 접근하는 것 자체가 문제였고, PM(PM) 혼자서 이해하거나 해결하기 어려울 때 같이 트러블슈팅(troubleshoot)해줄 사람이 없으면 더 막혔죠. 그래서 다른 팀에 가서 누군가의 리소스(resources)를 빌려 이 문제를 봐 달라고 조율해야 했어요. 그게 한 가지 큰 문제였어요.
text_zh: 从我做产品经理的经验来看，这个一直都是个障碍。想要拿到数据，或者找个人帮你排查问题，如果你作为PM自己搞不定的话，这就一直卡在那儿。然后你还得去跟其他团队谈，让他们分个人手来看这个问题，这是其中一点。
text_es: Por mi experiencia como product manager, siempre era un cuello de botella (blocker). El poder acceder a los datos, tal vez tener a alguien con quien resolver problemas si como PM no podías como que entenderlo o resolverlo tú solo, simplemente siempre era un obstáculo. Y entonces también tenías que ir a negociar con otros equipos para conseguir que alguien dedicara recursos a mirar este problema, eso es una cosa.
context: Lenny asks why Nikita pushes to embed data scientists directly into product teams rather than having them in a centralized data team. Nikita explains that when data scientists are centralized, product managers constantly face delays in getting data analysis done. They have to negotiate with other teams for data science resources and wait in queues, which slows down product development. Having a dedicated data scientist on each product team eliminates these bottlenecks and allows for faster decision-making.
vocabulary_highlights: getting your hands on, troubleshoot with, figure it out yourself, negotiate with

speaker: Nikita Miller
speaker_expertise: Product Management, Team Building, Growth Strategy
text: I'll tell you what I do. I don't know, I think folks might get defensive sometime. But I'll tell you what I try. For me the biggest thing is just if folks are working on a sprint, it's very simply, 'What did you deliver this sprint?' That's it. Just ask a bunch of questions. 'What did you deliver?' And more questions, 'Okay, fine, but what did you deliver to production? Great. And how long have you been working on that? How long? What was the cycle time?'
text_ko: 제가 어떻게 하는지 말해드릴게요. 글쎄요, 사람들은 가끔 방어적으로 나올 때가 있는 것 같아요. 그래도 제가 시도하는 건 이거예요. 제일 중요한 건 스프린트(sprint) 동안 사람들이 실제로 뭘 했는지예요. 아주 단순하게 "이번 스프린트에서 무엇을 배포했나요?" 그게 전부예요. 그냥 질문을 막 던져요. "무엇을 배포했나요?" 그리고 더 물어봐요. "좋아요, 그런데 그걸 프로덕션(production)에 배포했나요?" "잘했네요. 그걸 얼마나 오래 작업했나요? 얼마나요? 사이클 타임(cycle time)은 어땠나요?"
text_zh: 我跟你说我是怎么做的。我也不知道，可能有些人会觉得不舒服吧。但我告诉你我的做法。对我来说最重要的就是，如果团队在做冲刺(sprint)的话，很简单，就问"这个冲刺你们交付了什么？"就这样。就是不停地问问题。"你们交付了什么？"然后接着问，"好吧，那你们实际上线了什么？很好。那你们在这上面花了多长时间？多久？周期时间(cycle time)是多少？"
text_es: Te voy a decir lo que hago yo. No sé, creo que a veces la gente se puede poner a la defensiva. Pero te cuento lo que trato de hacer. Para mí lo más importante es simplemente, si el equipo está trabajando en un sprint, muy sencillo: "¿Qué entregaron en este sprint?" Y ya. Nada más hacer un montón de preguntas. "¿Qué entregaron?" Y más preguntas: "Bueno, está bien, ¿pero qué subieron a producción? Perfecto. ¿Y cuánto tiempo llevan trabajando en eso? ¿Cuánto tiempo? ¿Cuál fue el tiempo de ciclo (cycle time)?"
context: Lenny asks how to help teams recognize when they're not delivering enough output without making them defensive. Nikita shares her approach of asking direct but non-accusatory questions about actual deliverables. Rather than making statements about poor performance, she focuses on understanding what was actually shipped to production and how long it took. This questioning approach helps teams self-reflect on their execution velocity while avoiding defensiveness that comes from direct criticism.
vocabulary_highlights: get defensive, ask a bunch of questions, cycle time

speaker: Nikita Miller
speaker_expertise: Product Management, Team Building, Growth Strategy
text: When I reflect back on what works across my early career, it really comes down in a nutshell to this career concept of explore and exploit. You're either in a mode of explorer where you have a bunch of unknowns and you're testing to see whether or not you like it, or you're exploiting, where you actually have found something that's really rich and really deep.
text_ko: 제 경력 초반에 뭐가 통했나 돌아보면, 한마디로 경력 개념인 '탐색과 활용(explore and exploit)'으로 정리돼요. 보통은 미지의 게 많아서 이 일이 맞는지, 내가 좋아하는지 시험해보는 탐색자 모드(explorer)에 있거나, 아니면 정말 깊고 가치 있는 무언가를 찾아내 그걸 깊이 파고들며 활용하는 활용 모드(exploit)에 있어요.
text_zh: 回头想想我职业生涯早期什么管用，说白了就是两个字：探索和深耕。要么你在探索模式，面对一堆未知的东西，试试看自己到底喜不喜欢；要么你在深耕模式，已经找到了真正有价值、有深度的东西，就使劲挖下去。
text_es: Cuando reflexiono sobre lo que me funcionó en mis primeros años profesionales, todo se resume básicamente en este concepto de carrera: explorar y explotar. O estás en modo explorador, donde tienes un montón de incógnitas y estás probando a ver si te gusta, o estás explotando, donde ya encontraste algo que realmente vale la pena y tiene mucha profundidad.
context: Lenny asks about Nikita's biggest lessons for building successful teams, and she shifts to discussing team building fundamentals. Nikita explains that successful team building starts with clearly defining individual roles and responsibilities, particularly within cross-functional product teams. She advocates for what she calls a 'quartet' approach - expanding the traditional product-design-engineering triad to include data scientists as a fourth core member of product teams.
vocabulary_highlights: in a nutshell, mode of explorer, bunch of unknowns, really rich and really deep

speaker: Nikita Miller
speaker_expertise: Product Management, Team Building, Growth Strategy
text: So when I say outcome, you're saying here's the goal they're achieving or the impact they're having, or is it just the idea we know what our outcome will be but they're not actually shipping anything? The outcomes are understanding what the goals are and what we might do to get there. So OKRs is one way to talk about that. Great. But embedded in that is and how are we going to get there? And the fact is, the more tries you have at it, the likelier you are to get it right.
text_ko: 제가 '성과(outcome)'라고 말할 때, 당신은 그들이 달성하려는 목표나 만들어내는 영향(impact)을 말하는 건가요, 아니면 결과는 알고 있는데 실제로는 아무 것도 출시(shipping)하지 않는다는 뜻인가요? 성과라는 건 목표가 무엇인지, 그리고 그 목표에 도달하기 위해 우리가 무엇을 할 수 있을지 이해하는 거예요. 그래서 OKR(목표와 핵심 결과, OKRs)이 그걸 이야기하는 한 방법이에요. 좋은 접근이에요. 그런데 거기에는 '우리는 어떻게 그 목표에 도달할 것인가?'라는 질문이 포함돼 있어요. 그리고 사실 여러 번 시도해볼수록 정답을 맞출 가능성이 더 커져요.
text_zh: 所以我说到结果的时候，你是指他们要达成的目标或者产生的影响，还是说我们只是知道会有什么结果，但实际上他们什么都没做出来？这里说的结果就是要搞清楚目标是什么，我们可能怎么去实现。所以OKR就是讨论这个的一种方法。很好。但这里面还包含一个问题——我们怎么去实现？事实上就是，你尝试的次数越多，成功的可能性就越大。
text_es: Entonces cuando digo resultado, ¿te refieres a que aquí está la meta que están logrando o el impacto que están teniendo, o es solo la idea de que sabemos cuál va a ser nuestro resultado pero en realidad no están entregando nada? Los resultados tienen que ver con entender cuáles son los objetivos y qué podríamos hacer para llegar ahí. Los OKRs son una forma de hablar de eso. Perfecto. Pero dentro de eso está el cómo vamos a llegar ahí. Y la realidad es que mientras más intentos tengas, más probable es que le atines.
context: Lenny asks Nikita to clarify what she means by outcomes versus output after she mentioned teams focusing too heavily on outcomes. Nikita explains that outcomes refer to understanding goals and strategy (like OKRs), but teams often get stuck in planning mode. She emphasizes that successful execution requires multiple attempts and iterations - the more experiments and products you ship to market, the higher your chances of achieving your desired outcomes. The key is balancing strategic thinking with actual delivery.
vocabulary_highlights: embedded in that, the more tries you have at it, the likelier you are

speaker: Nilan Peiris
speaker_expertise: Growth Strategy, User Experience, Product Strategy
text: Some people focus on conversion rate, like, "I'm going to make this really, really slick." And that's cool. You get a bit more growth. But to get to recommendation, you're going to blow your user socks off. You have to give them an experience they didn't know was previously possible. And when you are in that place of doing something that no one has ever done before, that's when you get it.
text_ko: 어떤 사람들은 전환율(conversion rate)에만 신경 쓰면서 "이걸 정말 깔끔하게 만들 거야"라고 해요. 그건 좋아요, 어느 정도 성장도 얻고요. 하지만 추천(recommendation)까지 가려면 사용자를 완전히 놀라게 해야 해요. 이전에는 그런 게 가능하다고도 생각하지 못했던 경험을 줘야 해요. 그리고 아무도 해본 적 없는 걸 해냈을 때 비로소 그게 따라와요.
text_zh: 有些人就盯着转化率(conversion rate)，想着"我要把这个做得特别特别炫"。这也挺好的，能带来一些增长。但是要想让用户主动推荐你，那就得让他们彻底震撼到。你得给他们一种他们以前想都想不到的体验。当你做出了前无古人的东西时，那就对了。
text_es: Hay gente que se enfoca solo en la tasa de conversión, como "voy a hacer esto súper pulido y elegante." Y está bien, logras crecer un poco más. Pero para llegar a que te recomienden, tienes que dejar a tus usuarios completamente impresionados (blow their socks off). Tienes que darles una experiencia que ni sabían que era posible. Y cuando estás en ese punto de hacer algo que nadie ha hecho antes, ahí es cuando lo logras.
context: Lenny is discussing with Nilan how to drive word-of-mouth growth for products. Nilan is explaining that most teams stop when their product simply works, or they focus on incremental improvements like conversion rate optimization. However, to get customers to actively recommend your product to others, you need to exceed their expectations dramatically. He argues that you must create experiences that customers never knew were possible before - essentially doing something completely new rather than just improving existing solutions.
vocabulary_highlights: blow your user socks off, in that place of

speaker: Nilan Peiris
speaker_expertise: Growth Strategy, User Experience, Product Strategy
text: So building a brand led money transfer business, the brand's got to be pretty damn good, right? You're going to feel pretty special afterwards, in order to have less money afterwards. So what we're looking for always, but what channels out there are super scalable, and can reach our entire audience, but have an incredibly low distribution cost.
text_ko: 그래서 브랜드 주도형 송금 비즈니스(brand-led money transfer business)를 만들려면 브랜드가 정말 좋아야 해요, 그렇죠? 결국 돈이 줄어들 텐데도 사람들이 '나 특별하네'라고 느껴야 하니까요. 그래서 우리가 항상 찾는 건 어떤 채널(channels)이 엄청 확장 가능(scalable)하고 전체 고객층(audience)에 닿을 수 있으면서 배포 비용(distribution cost)이 아주 낮은지예요.
text_zh: 所以要做品牌驱动的转账业务，这个品牌得相当牛才行，对吧？用户花了钱之后还得觉得特别值，钱虽然少了但心里美滋滋的。所以我们一直在找的就是，哪些渠道既能大规模推广，又能覆盖我们所有的目标用户，但是推广成本还特别低。
text_es: Entonces, para construir un negocio de transferencias de dinero basado en marca, la marca tiene que estar súper buena, ¿no? El cliente se tiene que sentir muy especial después, para justificar que se quede con menos dinero. Así que lo que siempre buscamos es qué canales por ahí son súper escalables, que puedan llegar a toda nuestra audiencia, pero que tengan un costo de distribución increíblemente bajo.
context: Lenny asks about the biggest shift that helped Wise grow word-of-mouth significantly. Nilan explains why word-of-mouth was essential for Wise's business model. Since money is the ultimate commodity and customers end up with less money after using any money transfer service, building a brand-led business in this space requires an exceptionally good customer experience. He's outlining the challenge of finding marketing channels that can scale broadly while having very low distribution costs, which led them to focus on word-of-mouth growth.
vocabulary_highlights: pretty damn good, super scalable, incredibly low distribution cost

speaker: Nilan Peiris
speaker_expertise: Growth Strategy, User Experience, Product Strategy
text: We only got the advocacy when we were eight to 10 times cheaper. That's when people started talking about it. So the bar is all the way up there. And to put that in context, that means figuring out how to move money instantly. That means figuring out how to drop the price all the way from six all the way down to 0.35.
text_ko: 우리는 가격이 8~10배쯤 더 낮았을 때만 고객들의 지지(advocacy)를 얻었어요. 그때야 사람들이 입소문을 내기 시작했죠. 그래서 기준이 훨씬 높아졌어요. 좀 더 풀어 말하면, 돈을 즉시 옮기는 방법(move money instantly)을 찾아야 한다는 뜻이에요. 즉 단가를 6에서 0.35까지 완전히 낮추는 방법을 찾아야 해요.
text_zh: 只有当我们的价格便宜了8到10倍的时候，才真正赢得了用户的支持。那时候大家才开始议论我们。所以说这个门槛是相当高的。具体来说就是，我们得想办法实现瞬时转账，还得把价格从6块钱一路降到3毛5。
text_es: Solo conseguimos que la gente nos recomendara cuando éramos 8 o 10 veces más baratos. Ahí fue cuando empezaron a hablar de nosotros. O sea, el listón está súper alto. Y para que te hagas una idea de lo que significa esto, hablamos de conseguir que el dinero se mueva al instante. Hablamos de bajar el precio desde seis hasta 0.35.
context: Nilan is explaining a key insight about driving word-of-mouth for Wise. When entering new markets, they discovered that being marginally better (like pricing at 5.9% versus competitors at 6%) would get customers to use their service, but wouldn't generate recommendations. Only when they achieved dramatically better pricing - 8 to 10 times cheaper than alternatives - did customers become evangelical and start talking about the product. This taught them that the bar for recommendation is extremely high, requiring breakthrough improvements rather than incremental ones.
vocabulary_highlights: the bar is all the way up there, all the way down

speaker: Nilan Peiris
speaker_expertise: Growth Strategy, User Experience, Product Strategy
text: It's this thing around growth rate. So, especially product net growth, which is what we're talking about. So you can imagine, we're going to open a new market to Indonesia, and the fastest way to do it is to take... Someone else has figured out how to move to Indonesia. We take that infrastructure, and we'll plug it into Wise, you know what? We can do this, we'll get some users. But it doesn't grow like a hockey stick.
text_ko: 바로 성장률(growth rate)에 관한 얘기예요. 특히 우리가 말하는 건 제품 순성장(product net growth)이구요. 예를 들어 우리가 인도네시아 시장을 새로 열려 한다고 하면, 가장 빠른 방법은… 이미 누군가가 인도네시아로 진출하는 방법을 알아냈잖아요. 그 인프라를 가져다가 우리 서비스에 붙이면, '이건 할 수 있겠다' 해서 사용자 몇 명은 얻을 수 있어요. 근데 그게 하키스틱(hockey stick)처럼 확 폭발적으로 성장하진 않아요.
text_zh: 就是关于增长率的问题。特别是产品净增长，这就是我们在讨论的。你可以想象，我们要进入印尼这个新市场，最快的方式就是找到...别人已经摸清了怎么进入印尼市场。我们拿过来那套基础设施，然后接到Wise平台上，你知道吧？我们确实可以这么做，也能获得一些用户。但是这样不会出现爆发式增长(hockey stick growth)。
text_es: Es esto del ritmo de crecimiento. O sea, especialmente el crecimiento neto del producto, que es de lo que estamos hablando. Entonces te puedes imaginar, vamos a abrir un nuevo mercado en Indonesia, y la forma más rápida de hacerlo es tomar... Alguien más ya se las ingenió para entrar a Indonesia. Tomamos esa infraestructura, y la conectamos a Wise, ¿sabes qué? Podemos hacer esto, vamos a conseguir algunos usuarios. Pero no crece como palo de hockey (hockey stick).
context: Lenny asks about common mistakes people make when trying to drive word-of-mouth growth. Nilan explains a key misstep that many companies, including Wise, have made. When entering new markets, the tempting shortcut is to use existing infrastructure solutions that others have already built - for example, plugging into existing money transfer systems for Indonesia. While this approach can quickly acquire some users, it doesn't create the exponential growth curve needed for strong word-of-mouth because it hasn't fundamentally solved the underlying problems customers face.
vocabulary_highlights: grow like a hockey stick, plug it into

speaker: Nilan Peiris
speaker_expertise: Growth Strategy, User Experience, Product Strategy
text: So it comes from a very logical place, how do I get users quickly? I can take a shortcut in doing this, but that, you kind of realize is wasted effort. So the step then becomes this much harder question of these types of questions. Like what is the theoretical minimum cost for moving money into a market? What is the theoretical maximum speed?
text_ko: 이건 굉장히 논리적인 출발이에요. '어떻게 하면 사용자들을 빨리 모을 수 있을까?'에서 시작하죠. 지름길을 써서 해볼 수도 있는데, 그게 결국엔 쓸데없는 수고였다는 걸 깨닫게 돼요. 그래서 다음 단계는 훨씬 더 어려운 질문들로 옮겨가요. 예를 들어, 시장에 자금을 유입시키는 데(moving money into a market)의 이론상 최소 비용(theoretical minimum cost)은 얼마일까? 이론상 최대 속도(theoretical maximum speed)는 어느 정도일까?
text_zh: 所以这个想法其实很合理，就是我怎么能快速获客？我可以走捷径，但后来你会发现这其实是白费功夫。然后问题就变成了更难回答的那种，比如说，把资金投入市场的理论最低成本是多少？理论上的最高速度又是什么？
text_es: Entonces viene de un lugar muy lógico, ¿cómo consigo usuarios rápido? Puedo tomar un atajo para hacer esto, pero eso, te das cuenta de que es esfuerzo perdido. Entonces el paso se convierte en esta pregunta mucho más difícil, este tipo de preguntas. Como ¿cuál es el costo teórico mínimo para mover dinero a un mercado? ¿Cuál es la velocidad teórica máxima?
context: Continuing his explanation about avoiding shortcuts in product development, Nilan describes how teams naturally want to find quick wins to acquire users rapidly. However, he learned that these shortcuts ultimately represent wasted effort because they don't create the transformative experiences needed for word-of-mouth growth. Instead, teams should ask fundamental questions about the theoretical limits of what's possible - like the absolute minimum cost or maximum speed achievable - and work backwards from those ideals rather than making incremental improvements.
vocabulary_highlights: wasted effort, theoretical minimum, theoretical maximum

speaker: Nilan Peiris
speaker_expertise: Growth Strategy, User Experience, Product Strategy
text: You can't split test your way to love. So, this experiment led product management approach, where you throw a bunch of things on the wall, and then you kind of see what sticks, and generally we don't advocate this. Obviously there's a bit of it that happens, but generally don't advocate it. Mainly because engineering is expensive, and you can actually figure out what matters to customers through other means.
text_ko: A/B 테스트(A/B test)만으로 사용자의 '사랑'을 얻을 수는 없어요. 그래서 여러 가지를 닥치는 대로 시도해 보고 뭐가 통하는지 보는 실험 주도형 제품 관리 접근법(experiment-led product management)은 보통 추천하지 않아요. 물론 어느 정도 그런 일이 일어나긴 하지만, 전반적으로 권장하지 않아요. 주된 이유는 엔지니어링(engineering)이 비용이 많이 들고, 고객에게 정말 중요한 게 무엇인지는 다른 방법으로도 충분히 파악할 수 있기 때문이에요.
text_zh: 你不能靠A/B测试来获得用户的喜爱。所以说，这种实验导向的产品管理方式，就是往墙上扔一堆东西，然后看看哪个能粘住，我们一般不太推荐这么做。当然了，这种情况肯定会有一些，但总的来说我们不建议这样。主要是因为开发成本很高，而且你其实可以通过别的方式来搞清楚客户真正在意什么。
text_es: No puedes hacer A/B testing para conseguir que la gente se enamore de tu producto. Entonces, este enfoque experimental en gestión de producto, donde lanzas un montón de cosas a ver qué funciona, pues en general no lo recomendamos. Obvio que algo de esto siempre pasa, pero por lo general no lo recomendamos. Principalmente porque el desarrollo es caro, y en realidad puedes averiguar qué les importa a los clientes por otros medios.
context: Lenny and Nilan are discussing Wise's approach to product development and experimentation. Nilan is explaining why Wise doesn't rely heavily on A/B testing and experiment-driven product management. He argues that constantly running experiments to see what works is ineffective for building products that customers will love and recommend. Instead of this "throw things at the wall" approach, he advocates for building conviction about what matters to customers through direct customer feedback and insights before building features, since engineering resources are expensive and limited.
vocabulary_highlights: split test your way to love, throw a bunch of things on the wall, see what sticks

speaker: Nilan Peiris
speaker_expertise: Growth Strategy, User Experience, Product Strategy
text: And closing this delta between what you've done, and what's perceived to be done is what I call product marketing within the product. And that in its own right is a discipline, I've learned.
text_ko: 여러분이 실제로 해놓은 것과 사람들이 해놓은 것으로 인식하는 것 사이의 격차를 줄이는 것이 제가 말하는 제품 안에서의 프로덕트 마케팅(product marketing within the product)이에요. 그리고 그게 그 자체로 하나의 전문 분야라는 걸 배웠어요.
text_zh: 要缩小你实际做的事情和别人认为你做的事情之间的差距，我把这叫做产品内的产品营销(product marketing within the product)。我发现这本身就是一门学问。
text_es: Y cerrar esa brecha entre lo que realmente has hecho y lo que se percibe que has hecho es lo que yo llamo marketing del producto dentro del producto. Y eso por sí solo es toda una disciplina, he aprendido.
context: Nilan is sharing insights about a breakthrough that 3x'd their referral sharing rates. He discovered that customers were getting great value from Wise but weren't fully aware of how much value they were receiving. For example, customers saved money but didn't believe the actual savings amount, or received instant transfers without realizing they were instant. The key was creating visual comparisons and animations within the product to help customers understand the true value they received, which then made them more likely to share with others.
vocabulary_highlights: closing this delta, in its own right

speaker: Nir Eyal
text: I went to Alibaba and I bought myself one of these flip phones from China like we used to have in the 1990s with no apps, no internet connection. And then I got myself a word processor off of eBay so that I could just sit down and write and do the important stuff. And even when I stopped using all the technology, even when I got rid of all the apps, I would sit down on my desk and I'd say, "Oh, you know what? There's that book that I've been meaning what to do some research in," or, "Let me just clean off my desk real quick," or, "You know what? I should take out the trash."
text_ko: 알리바바에 가서 1990년대에 쓰던 것처럼 중국산 플립폰(flip phone) 하나를 샀어요. 앱(apps)도 없고 인터넷 연결(internet connection)도 안 되는 그런 거예요. 그리고 이베이(eBay)에서 워드 프로세서(word processor)를 하나 구해서 그냥 앉아서 글만 쓰고 중요한 일만 하려고 했어요. 그런데 기술을 다 끊고 앱도 다 지웠는데도 책상에 앉으면 "아, 맞다, 내가 좀 조사해보려고 했던 그 책이 있지"라든가 "책상만 좀 치울까", "쓰레기라도 버려야겠다" 같은 생각이 자꾸 들더라고요.
text_zh: 我去阿里巴巴上给自己买了个中国产的翻盖手机，就像我们90年代用的那种，没有任何应用，也连不上网。然后我又在eBay上买了台文字处理器，这样我就能专心坐下来写东西，做真正重要的事。但是你知道吗，就算我不用那些科技产品了，就算我把所有应用都删了，我坐在桌子前还是会想："哎，对了，有本书我一直想查点资料"，或者"让我先把桌子收拾一下"，再不就是"我应该去倒个垃圾"。
text_es: Me metí a Alibaba y me compré uno de esos teléfonos de tapa de China como los que teníamos en los noventa, sin aplicaciones ni conexión a internet. Y después me conseguí un procesador de textos en eBay para poder sentarme tranquilo a escribir y hacer lo importante. Pero incluso cuando dejé de usar toda la tecnología, cuando me deshice de todas las apps, me sentaba en mi escritorio y decía: "Ah, ¿sabes qué? Ahí está ese libro en el que quería investigar algo", o "Déjame ordenar el escritorio rapidito", o "¿Sabes qué? Debería sacar la basura".
context: Lenny asks Nir about his personal experience with distraction and what techniques he tried. Nir explains how he attempted to solve his distraction problem by completely removing technology from his environment - buying a basic flip phone and an old word processor. However, he discovered that even without any digital distractions, he still found ways to procrastinate and avoid the important work he needed to do. This led him to realize that the root cause of distraction isn't external technology, but internal discomfort.
vocabulary_highlights: I've been meaning, real quick, take out the trash

speaker: Nir Eyal
text: So, what I have adopted for myself and what I'd advise anyone who finds themselves in this situation is to always identify what is that internal trigger, what is that itch that you are looking to escape when you get distracted, because that is the source of 90% of our distractions. It's not the pings, dings, and rings. It's the feelings. But to me, that's incredibly empowering because once you realize, "Wait a minute, it's just a feeling." It's all it is, it's just an emotion. Then you can have tools ready to go. You can have arrows in your quiver ready to take out as soon as you feel that discomfort.
text_ko: 그래서 제가 제 자신에게 적용한 방법이자 이런 상황에 처한 누구에게나 권하고 싶은 건요, 항상 그 내적 트리거(internal trigger)가 뭔지, 주의가 산만해질 때 벗어나고 싶게 만드는 그 근질거림이 뭔지 먼저 찾아보라는 거예요. 사실 우리의 산만함(distraction)의 90%는 바로 거기서 오거든요. 핑·딩·벨소리 같은 알림음 때문이 아니라 그 감정 때문이에요. 그런데 제게는 그게 오히려 엄청난 힘이 되는 깨달음이에요. '잠깐, 그냥 느낌이구나'라고 인지하면 모든 게 달라지거든요. 그러면 미리 쓸 도구들을 준비해 두고, 불편함이 느껴지자마자 꺼내 쓸 대응책들—비유하자면 화살통에 화살을 담아두는 것처럼—을 갖춰둘 수 있어요.
text_zh: 所以，我自己的做法，也是我建议任何遇到这种情况的人去做的，就是一定要搞清楚那个内在触发点(internal trigger)是什么，就是当你分心的时候，你到底想逃避的那种心里痒痒的感觉是什么，因为这才是我们90%分心的根源。不是那些手机的叮咚响声，而是我们内心的感受。但对我来说，这个发现特别有力量，因为一旦你意识到，"等等，这就是一种感觉而已。"就这么简单，就是一种情绪罢了。那你就可以准备好各种应对工具了。你可以在箭袋里准备好各种箭，一感觉到不舒服就马上拿出来用。
text_es: Entonces, lo que he adoptado para mí y lo que le recomendaría a cualquiera que se encuentre en esta situación es siempre identificar cuál es ese disparador interno (internal trigger), cuál es esa comezón de la que estás tratando de escapar cuando te distraes, porque esa es la fuente del 90% de nuestras distracciones. No son los pitidos, timbres y sonidos. Son los sentimientos. Pero para mí, eso es increíblemente empoderador porque una vez que te das cuenta de que "Oye, espera, es solo un sentimiento." Eso es todo, es solo una emoción. Entonces puedes tener herramientas listas para usar. Puedes tener flechas en tu aljaba (quiver) preparadas para sacar en cuanto sientes esa incomodidad.
context: Nir continues explaining his discovery about the true source of distraction. He reveals that research shows 90% of distractions come from internal triggers (emotions like boredom, anxiety, or discomfort) rather than external triggers like notifications. He emphasizes that understanding this is empowering because emotions are temporary and manageable. The 'arrows in your quiver' metaphor refers to having multiple strategies prepared to handle uncomfortable feelings when they arise, rather than escaping them through distraction.
vocabulary_highlights: internal trigger, that itch, pings, dings, and rings, arrows in your quiver
topics: Learning & Growth, Decision Making, Work-Life Balance

speaker: Nir Eyal
text: What I tell myself is, "Okay, I'm just going to wait 10 minutes before I check email, before I scroll social media, before I Google something that is just trying to procrastinate doing the work." I can do that. I'm a grown man. I can do whatever I want. I can do that in 10 minutes. And so, for those 10 minutes, all I have to do is either get back to the task at hand, get back to writing, or surf the urge, which is simply experiencing that sensation, acknowledging, "You know what? This is hard work. That's okay. That's why I'm feeling frustrated. That's why I'm feeling bored. That's why I'm feeling anxious."
text_ko: 저는 스스로에게 이렇게 말해요. "좋아, 이메일 확인하기 전에, 소셜 미디어를 스크롤하기 전에, 일을 미루려고 뭔가를 구글링하기 전에 10분만 기다리자." 그 정도는 할 수 있어요. 전 어른이고 제가 하고 싶은 건 할 수 있죠. 10분이면 충분해요. 그래서 그 10분 동안 제가 할 일은 지금 하던 일로 돌아가거나 글쓰기로 다시 집중하거나, 아니면 충동을 관찰하기(urge surfing)를 하는 것뿐이에요. 그건 그 느낌을 그냥 겪으면서, "아, 이건 힘든 일이구나. 괜찮아. 그래서 답답하고 지루하고 불안한 거구나." 하고 인정하는 거예요.
text_zh: 我就跟自己说："好吧，我先等十分钟再去看邮件，再去刷社交媒体，再去谷歌搜那些其实就是在拖延正事的东西。"这个我能做到。我是个成年人了，想做什么都行，十分钟后再做这些也没问题。所以在这十分钟里，我就做两件事：要么回到手头的活儿，继续写东西；要么就让这种冲动过去，就是感受一下这种感觉，然后承认："你知道吗？这活儿确实不好干，没关系的。所以我才会觉得烦躁，觉得无聊，觉得焦虑。"
text_es: Lo que me digo es: "Bueno, voy a esperar 10 minutos antes de revisar el email, antes de meterme a redes sociales, antes de buscar algo en Google que solo es para procrastinar y no hacer el trabajo." Eso sí puedo hacerlo. Soy un adulto. Puedo hacer lo que quiera. Puedo esperar 10 minutos. Entonces, durante esos 10 minutos, lo único que tengo que hacer es volver a la tarea, regresar a escribir, o aguantar el impulso, que simplemente es sentir esa sensación y reconocer: "¿Sabes qué? Este trabajo está difícil. No pasa nada. Por eso me siento frustrado. Por eso me siento aburrido. Por eso me siento ansioso."
context: Nir explains his '10-minute rule' technique for managing distraction urges. When he feels tempted to check social media or email instead of doing important work, he sets a timer for 10 minutes and tells himself he can do those distracting activities after the timer goes off - but not yet. During those 10 minutes, he either returns to his intended task or 'surfs the urge' by acknowledging and experiencing the uncomfortable emotion without trying to escape it. This technique treats the urge as temporary rather than permanent.
vocabulary_highlights: scroll social media, task at hand, surf the urge
topics: Learning & Growth, Decision Making, Work-Life Balance

speaker: Nir Eyal
text: You can't call something a distraction unless you know what it distracted you from. I'll say that again. You can't call something a distraction unless you know what it distracted you from. So, for me, at least, when I would succumb to, "Oh, let me just check email for a quick minute, let me just see what's happening on Twitter for a quick minute," part of that was because I would justify to myself, "Well, this is a work-related task. I got to do it sometime," and there wasn't a specific time to do it on my calendar, so I would keep thinking, "Well, I got to do it sometime. Might as well just do it now."
text_ko: 무엇 때문에 주의가 흐트러졌는지 모르면 그걸 산만하다고 부를 수 없어요. 다시 말할게요. 무엇 때문에 주의가 흐트러졌는지 모르면 그걸 산만하다고 부를 수 없어요. 적어도 제 경우엔, "이메일 잠깐만 확인해볼까, 트위터에서 뭐 있는지 잠깐만 볼까" 하고 유혹에 넘어갈 때가 있었는데, 그 이유 중 하나는 스스로에게 "이건 업무 관련이니까 언젠가는 해야 할 일이야"라고 합리화했기 때문이에요. 근데 캘린더에 딱 정해둔 시간이 없으니 계속 "언젠가는 해야 하니까 지금 하는 게 낫지"라고 생각하게 됐던 거예요.
text_zh: 你要是不知道自己本来该干什么，就没资格说别的事情让你分心了。我再说一遍啊，你要是不知道自己本来该干什么，就没资格说别的事情让你分心了。就拿我自己来说吧，以前我总是忍不住想"哎呀，我就快速看一眼邮件，就看一分钟"，或者"我就瞄一眼推特(Twitter)上有什么动态，就一分钟"，其实很大程度上是因为我会给自己找借口，想着"这也算工作相关的事儿嘛，反正早晚得做"，但我日程表上又没专门安排时间来处理这些事，所以就老想着"反正早晚得做，不如现在就做了吧"。
text_es: No puedes decir que algo te distrajo si no sabes de qué te distrajo. Lo voy a repetir. No puedes decir que algo te distrajo si no sabes de qué te distrajo. Entonces, por lo menos en mi caso, cuando caía en el "Ah, déjame revisar el email rapidito, déjame ver qué está pasando en Twitter un momentito," parte de eso era porque me justificaba pensando, "Bueno, esto es algo relacionado con el trabajo. Lo tengo que hacer en algún momento," y como no tenía un horario específico para hacerlo en mi calendario, seguía pensando, "Bueno, lo tengo que hacer en algún momento. Mejor lo hago ahorita."
context: Nir discusses the importance of having a scheduled plan to identify what constitutes distraction versus traction. He explains that without a clear calendar showing what you intended to do at specific times, it becomes easy to justify any work-related activity as productive. The key insight is that even checking work email can be a distraction if it's not what you planned to do during that time block. This justification trap keeps people from focusing on their most important tasks.
vocabulary_highlights: succumb to, for a quick minute, work-related task, might as well
topics: Decision Making, Strategy & Planning, Learning & Growth

speaker: Nir Eyal
text: What you want to do instead is to book time in your schedule for this reflective work time, which is where you do the kind of work that requires you to work without distraction. Planning, strategizing, thinking, for god's sakes, can only be done without distraction. So, that fills up your calendar, as well. And what you're going to find, that there's never enough time for everything, which is good because what this forces you to do, and this is one of the main reasons why to-do lists suck, is because to-do lists have no constraints.
text_ko: 대신 해야 할 건 이런 성찰적 작업 시간(reflective work time)을 일정에 미리 잡아두는 거예요. 이 시간에는 방해받지 않고 해야 하는 일들—계획 세우기, 전략 짜기, 정말로 깊게 생각하기 같은—을 하는 거예요. 그래서 일정도 금방 차게 돼요. 그러다 보면 모든 걸 다 할 시간은 결코 충분하지 않다는 걸 알게 될 거예요. 그런데 그게 오히려 좋은 이유는, 그게 당신에게 강제로 우선순위를 정하게 만들기 때문이에요. 이게 바로 할 일 목록(to-do lists)이 별로인 주된 이유 중 하나예요 — 할 일 목록에는 제약이 없으니까요.
text_zh: 你应该做的是在日程里专门安排时间来做这种需要深度思考的工作，就是那种必须专心致志、不能被打扰的活儿。规划啊、制定战略啊、思考问题啊，说真的，这些事儿只有在不被打扰的情况下才能做好。这样你的日历也就排满了。然后你会发现，时间永远不够用，但这其实是好事，因为这会逼着你做选择，这也是为什么待办清单(to-do list)不好用的主要原因——待办清单没有任何约束。
text_es: En cambio, lo que deberías hacer es bloquear tiempo en tu agenda para este trabajo de reflexión, que es donde haces el tipo de trabajo que necesita que te concentres sin distracciones. Planificar, crear estrategias, pensar, ¡por Dios!, solo se puede hacer sin distracciones. Así que esto también te va a llenar el calendario. Y lo que vas a descubrir es que nunca hay tiempo suficiente para todo, lo cual está bien porque esto te obliga a hacer algo, y esta es una de las razones principales por las que las listas de pendientes no sirven: porque las listas de pendientes no tienen límites.
context: Nir explains the importance of scheduling 'reflective work time' - periods dedicated to deep thinking, planning, and strategizing that require full attention. He distinguishes this from reactive work (responding to emails and notifications). He argues that to-do lists are inadequate because they lack time constraints - you can always add more items without considering how much time you actually have. A time-blocked calendar forces you to make realistic trade-offs and prioritize what truly matters.
vocabulary_highlights: reflective work time, for god's sakes, fills up your calendar, to-do lists suck
topics: Strategy & Planning, Decision Making, Learning & Growth

speaker: Nir Eyal
text: You don't tell your boss no, you ask your boss to help you prioritize. That is your boss' most important job is to prioritize. So, you're not saying no. You're saying, "Here's my calendar. Here's this list of stuff you've asked me to do. Help me prioritize." And here's what's going to happen. Your boss is going to look at your calendar and say, "You know what? That meeting, you really don't need to be at that meeting. But that thing on that piece of paper that you listed over here, that's way more important. Can you swap that out?"
text_ko: 상사한테 그냥 "안 돼요"라고 말하는 게 아니라, 상사에게 우선순위(prioritize)를 정해 달라고 요청하는 거예요. 사실 상사의 가장 중요한 역할 중 하나가 우선순위를 정하는 거예요. 그러니까 당신은 "아니요"라고 하는 게 아니라, "여기 제 캘린더예요. 여기 요청하신 업무 목록도 있어요. 우선순위를 도와주세요."라고 말하는 거예요. 그럼 어떻게 될까요? 상사가 캘린더를 보면서 "사실 그 회의에는 굳이 안 가도 돼요. 그런데 여기 적어둔 이 일이 훨씬 더 중요하네요. 그걸로 바꿔줄 수 있나요?"라고 말해 줄 거예요.
text_zh: 你不要直接跟老板说不行，而是要请老板帮你排个优先级。其实排优先级就是老板最重要的工作之一。所以你不是在拒绝，而是在说："老板你看，这是我的日程表，这是你让我做的那些事儿，你帮我理理头绪吧。" 然后会发生什么呢？你老板会看看你的安排，然后说："你知道吗，那个会议你其实不用参加。但是你这里写的这件事儿，这个重要多了。你能把时间调一下吗？"
text_es: A tu jefe no le dices que no, le pides que te ayude a priorizar. Esa es la función más importante de tu jefe: establecer prioridades. O sea, no estás diciendo que no. Estás diciendo: "Mira, aquí tienes mi agenda. Esta es la lista de todo lo que me has pedido que haga. Ayúdame a priorizar." ¿Y sabes qué va a pasar? Tu jefe va a ver tu agenda y te va a decir: "¿Sabes qué? Esa reunión, realmente no necesitas estar en esa reunión. Pero esto que pusiste aquí en tu lista, esto es muchísimo más importante. ¿Puedes cambiar una cosa por la otra?"
context: Nir addresses how to manage competing demands from your manager without saying 'no' directly. He calls this technique 'schedule syncing' or 'managing your manager.' Instead of refusing requests, you show your boss your time-blocked calendar and a separate list of additional tasks they've requested. You then ask them to help prioritize what's most important. This approach leverages the fact that prioritization is a key management responsibility while giving you control over your time.
vocabulary_highlights: help you prioritize, swap that out
topics: Communication Skills, Strategy & Planning, Leadership & Management

speaker: Nir Eyal
text: The antidote for impulsiveness is forethought. The antidote for impulsiveness is forethought. Fundamentally, distraction is an impulse control issue. That's all it is, and it's a skill like any other. We learn skills. Why do we expect that we should just be born with this innate skill to fight distraction? It's a skill like any other. And so, the antidote for impulsiveness is forethought. If we plan ahead, if we know that we're going to take steps a day to prevent getting distracted tomorrow, there's no distraction we can't overcome.
text_ko: 충동성에 대한 해독제는 사전 숙고(forethought)예요. 본질적으로 산만함은 충동 조절(impulse control)의 문제예요. 그게 전부고, 다른 기술(skill)들처럼 배워야 하는 능력이에요. 우리는 기술을 배워요. 왜 산만함을 이겨내는 이런 능력을 그냥 타고나야 한다고 생각하죠? 다른 기술과 다르지 않아요. 그래서 충동성에 대한 해독제는 사전 숙고예요. 미리 계획하고, "내일 산만해지지 않도록 이런 조치를 취하겠다"고 정해두면 못 이길 산만함이 없어요.
text_zh: 冲动的解药就是提前想好。冲动的解药就是提前想好。说白了，分心就是个自控力的问题，就这么简单，这跟其他技能一样。技能都是学出来的嘛。我们凭什么觉得自己天生就该有对抗分心的本事？这就是个技能，跟别的技能没什么两样。所以说，冲动的解药就是提前想好。如果我们提前规划，如果我们知道今天要采取一些措施来防止明天分心，那就没有克服不了的分心。
text_es: El remedio para ser impulsivo es pensar las cosas antes. En el fondo, distraerse es un tema de autocontrol, nada más. Es una habilidad como cualquier otra. Las habilidades se aprenden. ¿Por qué esperamos nacer ya sabiendo cómo luchar contra las distracciones? Es una habilidad como cualquier otra. Entonces, el remedio para ser impulsivo es pensar las cosas antes. Si planificamos con tiempo, si sabemos que vamos a tomar medidas hoy para no distraernos mañana, no hay distracción que no podamos vencer.
context: Nir provides his core philosophy for becoming indistractable. He emphasizes that distraction is fundamentally about impulse control, which is a learnable skill rather than an inherent character trait. His key insight is that the solution lies in planning ahead - taking deliberate steps today to prevent tomorrow's distractions. This forward-thinking approach empowers people to take control of their attention rather than feeling helpless against distraction.
vocabulary_highlights: antidote for impulsiveness, forethought, impulse control issue, innate skill
topics: Learning & Growth, Decision Making, Strategy & Planning

speaker: Noah Weiss
speaker_expertise: Product Management, AI/ML Products, Product Design
text: We have this mental metaphor that we talk a lot about, getting to the next hill. The actual wording is "Take bigger boulder bets." I think teams can often get lost crawling up that hill, not realizing that there's a huge, incredibly beautiful range behind it where we've over time freighted new teams from scratch that incubated in a new area before the areas mature.
text_ko: 우리가 자주 쓰는 정신적 은유가 하나 있어요 — '다음 언덕으로 가는 것'이요. 원문 표현은 '더 큰 바위에 베팅하세요 (Take bigger boulder bets)'예요. 팀들은 종종 그 언덕을 기어오르느라 길을 잃어서, 그 뒤에 엄청나게 크고 아름다운 산맥이 펼쳐져 있다는 걸 깨닫지 못하곤 해요. 우리는 시간이 지나면서 새로운 영역이 본격적으로 성숙하기 전에 그곳에서 초기 단계로 키운 팀들을 처음부터 만들어 옮겨 배치해 왔어요.
text_zh: 我们经常用一个比喻来形容这种思维模式，就是"登上下一座山头"。具体的说法是"押注更大的石头"(Take bigger boulder bets)。我觉得团队往往会埋头苦干爬山，却没意识到山后面还有一片巨大的、美不胜收的山脉。我们一直以来都会从零开始组建新团队，让他们在新领域孵化项目，等这些领域成熟起来。
text_es: Tenemos esta metáfora mental de la que hablamos mucho: llegar a la siguiente colina. La frase exacta es "apostar por rocas más grandes" (take bigger boulder bets). Creo que los equipos a menudo se pierden arrastrándose por esa colina, sin darse cuenta de que hay una cordillera enorme e increíblemente hermosa detrás, donde con el tiempo hemos creado equipos completamente nuevos que se incubaron en áreas nuevas antes de que esas áreas maduraran.
context: At the beginning of the podcast, Noah explains Slack's approach to product innovation and avoiding incremental thinking. He describes how product teams can get trapped in constant small improvements without seeing bigger opportunities. The metaphor of "getting to the next hill" refers to moving beyond immediate tasks to see the broader landscape of possibilities that exists beyond current projects.
vocabulary_highlights: mental metaphor, boulder bets, crawling up that hill, incredibly beautiful range, freighted new teams
topics: Product Management, Strategy & Planning, Leadership & Management

speaker: Noah Weiss
speaker_expertise: Product Management, AI/ML Products, Product Design
text: I think the biggest probably lesson learned, frankly, is that we were really close with the Instagram folks early on. They were big developers on our platform. They used the Foursquare API before they were bought by Facebook. I think in hindsight we were a little bit mistaken to believe that the idea that the atomic unit would be a person talking about a place that they're at and you have to have a physical place to tie it to versus a person sharing a moment or an experience that they're having in the world.
text_ko: 솔직히 말하면, 가장 큰 교훈은 우리가 초기에 인스타그램 팀과 정말 가까웠다는 거예요. 그들은 우리 플랫폼에서 큰 개발자였고, 페이스북에 인수되기 전에 Foursquare API를 사용했어요. 지금 생각해보면, 우리가 '원자 단위(atomic unit)'가 사람과 그 사람이 있는 장소에 대한 이야기라는 생각을 좀 잘못한 것 같아요. 사실, 물리적인 장소에 연결해야 한다기보다, 사람들이 세상에서 경험하고 있는 순간이나 경험을 공유하는 게 더 중요했을 수도 있죠.
text_zh: 我觉得最大的教训，说实话，就是我们早期跟Instagram那帮人关系特别铁。他们算是我们平台上的大开发者，在被Facebook收购之前一直在用我们的Foursquare API。现在回头看，我觉得我们当时的想法有点问题——我们以为最基本的单位应该是一个人在谈论他所在的地方，必须得绑定到一个实体的地点，而不是一个人在分享他在世界上正在经历的某个瞬间或体验。
text_es: Creo que la lección más grande que aprendimos, la verdad, es que teníamos una relación muy estrecha con la gente de Instagram desde el principio. Eran grandes desarrolladores en nuestra plataforma. Usaban el API de Foursquare antes de que Facebook los comprara. Pienso que, visto en retrospectiva, nos equivocamos un poco al creer que la unidad básica sería una persona hablando de un lugar donde está y que tenías que vincularla a un lugar físico, en lugar de una persona compartiendo un momento o una experiencia que está viviendo en el mundo.
context: Lenny asks Noah whether Foursquare could have built a massive consumer business or if pivoting to B2B data was inevitable. Noah reflects on what went wrong with Foursquare's social strategy. He explains that they focused on location-based sharing (person + place) while Instagram succeeded with experience-based sharing (person + moment), which sometimes included location but wasn't dependent on it.
vocabulary_highlights: in hindsight, atomic unit, tie it to

speaker: Noah Weiss
speaker_expertise: Product Management, AI/ML Products, Product Design
text: I would say to folks in general, if you're joining company and the CEO does the role that is your functional area of expertise, it's probably the area where you'll learn the most because they're hopefully world class at it. But also, one will you'll be the most frustrated at times because you're going to feel like you have less agency.
text_ko: 일반적으로 드리는 말인데요, 입사해서 최고경영자(CEO)가 여러분의 전문 업무 영역(functional area)을 직접 맡고 있다면 그 분야에서 가장 많이 배우게 될 가능성이 커요 — 보통 그분들이 그 일에 대해 세계적 수준이니까요. 다만 동시에 가장 답답함을 느낄 때도 많은데, 그건 스스로 영향력을 발휘하기 어려워 자율성(agency)이 줄어든다고 느끼기 때문이에요.
text_zh: 我觉得大家要知道，如果你加入一家公司，而CEO恰好是你这个专业领域的专家，那这块儿你肯定能学到最多东西，因为他们在这方面应该是顶尖的。但同时呢，这也是最容易让你憋屈的地方，因为你会觉得自己没什么发挥空间，很多事情做不了主。
text_es: Yo les diría en general, si te unes a una empresa donde el CEO maneja el área que es tu especialidad, probablemente sea donde más vas a aprender porque se supone que es un crack en eso. Pero también va a ser donde más te frustres a veces, porque vas a sentir que tienes menos autonomía para tomar decisiones.
context: Lenny asks Noah about working with strong product-minded founders like Dennis Crowley and Stewart Butterfield. Noah shares advice for product managers joining companies where the CEO is deeply involved in product decisions. He explains the trade-off between learning opportunities and potential frustration when working under a product-focused founder who may limit your decision-making authority.
vocabulary_highlights: functional area of expertise, world class at it, less agency

speaker: Noah Weiss
speaker_expertise: Product Management, AI/ML Products, Product Design
text: I think what we would wind up doing with Stewart at Slack, for example, is we would get the entire development team, engineers design product, user research and Stewart together in a room and we almost do a bug bash together. The idea was like, "We're doing it all together. We're trying to make the best product possible, making great softwares really messy and we're all trying to clean up the mess together."
text_ko: 예를 들어 Slack에서 Stewart랑 같이 일할 때는 결국 개발팀 전체 — 엔지니어, 디자이너, 프로덕트팀, 유저 리서치(user research)와 Stewart를 한자리에 모아서 거의 다 같이 버그 배시(bug bash)를 했어요. 요지는 '우리 모두 같이 하는 거예요. 최고의 제품을 만들려고 하는데, 훌륭한 소프트웨어를 만드는 과정은 원래 되게 지저분하니까 그 지저분한 걸 다 같이 치워나가자'는 느낌이었어요.
text_zh: 我觉得我们在Slack和Stewart合作的时候，基本上就是把整个开发团队——工程师、设计师、产品经理、用户研究，还有Stewart，所有人都拉到一个房间里，然后一起做bug bash。就是那种"咱们一起搞定这事儿"的感觉。我们就想做出最好的产品，但是做好软件这事儿本来就很乱，所以大家一起收拾这个烂摊子。
text_es: Creo que lo que terminábamos haciendo con Stewart en Slack, por ejemplo, era juntar a todo el equipo de desarrollo - ingenieros, diseño, producto, investigación de usuarios y Stewart - todos en una sala y básicamente hacíamos como un bug bash juntos. La idea era "Lo vamos a hacer todos juntos. Estamos tratando de hacer el mejor producto posible, crear buen software es súper desordenado y todos estamos tratando de limpiar ese desorden juntos."
context: Noah explains how to successfully involve product-minded founders in the final stages of product development. He describes Slack's collaborative approach where the entire team, including founder Stewart Butterfield, would gather to review and refine products before launch. A "bug bash" is a collaborative session where team members test software together to find and fix issues.
vocabulary_highlights: wind up doing, bug bash, clean up the mess together

speaker: Noah Weiss
speaker_expertise: Product Management, AI/ML Products, Product Design
text: What we started doing with these complaints storms and idea was really simple, which is we'd get a team together often Stewart myself would also join and we'd actually start off with other products first in adjacent spaces and we'd say, "Okay. As a group we're going to go through the customer journey from the moment you land on the website through, let's say it's a workplace product, getting your first account going, getting the first couple of users on board, getting to the point of value."
text_ko: 우리가 이런 불만 폭주(complaints storms)랑 아이디어로 뭘 시작한 건 사실 되게 단순했어요. 팀을 모았고, 종종 스튜어트도 저도 같이 참여해서 실제로는 인접한 영역의 다른 제품들부터 먼저 살펴봤어요. 그리고 "좋아요, 우리 팀이 웹사이트에 들어온 순간부터 고객 여정(customer journey)을 쭉 따라가자"라고 했죠. 예를 들어 직장용 제품(workplace product)이라면 첫 계정을 만들고, 처음 몇 명의 사용자를 온보딩(onboard)하고, 가치를 느끼는 지점(point of value)에 도달하는 것까지요.
text_zh: 我们应对这些投诉风暴的做法其实很简单，就是把团队拉到一起，我和Stewart也经常会参与进来，然后我们会先从相关领域的其他产品开始着手，大家一起梳理整个用户旅程——从用户刚进入网站那一刻开始，比如说是个企业级产品的话，就跟着用户走完开通第一个账户、让前几个用户上手使用、一直到他们真正体验到产品价值的整个过程。
text_es: Lo que empezamos a hacer con estas oleadas de quejas y la idea era súper sencillo - juntábamos un equipo, muchas veces Stewart y yo también nos metíamos, y arrancábamos primero con otros productos de espacios relacionados. Decíamos, "Bueno, como grupo vamos a repasar todo el recorrido del cliente (customer journey) desde que aterriza en la web hasta, digamos si es un producto para empresas, activar su primera cuenta, subir a los primeros usuarios, y llegar hasta ese punto donde ven el valor real."
context: Lenny asks Noah about Slack's "Complaint-Storms" process. Noah explains this method for helping teams look at their product with fresh eyes and build empathy for new users. The process involves teams critically examining customer journeys in competing products first, then applying the same critical lens to their own product to identify pain points and areas for improvement.
vocabulary_highlights: complaints storms, adjacent spaces, get to the point of value

speaker: Noah Weiss
speaker_expertise: Product Management, AI/ML Products, Product Design
text: I think teams can often get lost crawling up that hill, not realizing that there's a huge, incredibly beautiful range behind it. Take bigger boulder bets. Get to the next hill to see what the horizon wants around you. That's how we think about it strategically.
text_ko: 팀들이 종종 그 언덕을 기어 올라가느라 정작 그 뒤에 엄청 크고 정말 멋진 산맥이 있다는 걸 모를 때가 많아요. 더 큰 바위 같은 베팅(boulder bets)을 해보세요. 다음 언덕까지 올라가서 주변의 지평선이 무엇을 보여주는지 확인해 보세요. 우리가 전략을 생각하는 방식이 바로 그거예요.
text_zh: 我觉得团队经常会陷在眼前这点小坡上爬不出来，根本没意识到后面还有一片超级美的大好河山。要敢于下大注，爬到下一个山头去看看周围到底有什么机会。这就是我们在战略上的思路。
text_es: Creo que los equipos muchas veces se quedan atascados subiendo esa cuesta, sin darse cuenta de que hay una cordillera enorme e increíblemente hermosa detrás. Hay que apostar por cosas más grandes, por proyectos que realmente muevan la aguja. Llegar a la siguiente colina para ver qué oportunidades te esperan en el horizonte. Así es como lo vemos estratégicamente.
context: Lenny asks how Slack enables innovation and zero-to-one bets despite being a large company. Noah explains Slack's strategic philosophy using a mountain climbing metaphor. He describes how teams can get trapped focusing on immediate incremental improvements ("crawling up that hill") without seeing the much larger opportunities that exist beyond their current scope.
vocabulary_highlights: crawling up that hill, incredibly beautiful range, boulder bets, what the horizon wants around you
topics: Strategy & Planning, Product Management, Leadership & Management

speaker: Noah Weiss
speaker_expertise: Product Management, AI/ML Products, Product Design
text: I think when we have those teams, I think it's important to just give them space to run, to give them ... get a gel free card for maybe the normal process of, "Okay. Our planning quarterly reviews" and make it feel something that is the pace of learning is what matters. How fast are you prototyping, how fast are you learning from users and then getting to do that publicly and pilot and then get something to launch that's amazing, blows people away.
text_ko: 그런 팀들이 있을 때는 그냥 마음껏 해볼 수 있는 여지를 주는 게 중요하다고 생각해요. 예를 들어 분기별 계획 검토(quarterly reviews) 같은 평소의 프로세스에서 잠시 자유로울 수 있는 일종의 면죄부를 줘서, 중요한 건 학습 속도(pace of learning)라는 느낌이 들게 해야 해요. 얼마나 빨리 프로토타이핑(prototyping)하고 사용자에게서 얼마나 빨리 배우느냐, 그걸 공개적으로 파일럿(pilot)해보고 결국 사람들을 완전히 놀라게 하는 멋진 결과물을 출시(launch)하는 속도가 핵심이에요.
text_zh: 我觉得当我们有这样的团队时，重要的是要给他们足够的空间去发挥，给他们一张免死金牌，让他们可以跳过那些常规流程，比如"好吧，我们的季度规划评审"这些，让他们感觉学习的节奏才是最重要的。你们原型做得多快？从用户那里学到东西的速度有多快？然后公开试点，最后推出一个让人眼前一亮的产品。
text_es: Creo que cuando tenemos esos equipos, es importante simplemente darles espacio para que corran, darles... como una carta libre para salirse del proceso normal de "bueno, nuestras revisiones trimestrales de planificación" y hacer que sientan que lo que importa es el ritmo de aprendizaje. Qué tan rápido están haciendo prototipos, qué tan rápido están aprendiendo de los usuarios y luego poder hacerlo públicamente como piloto y después sacar algo al mercado que sea increíble, que deje a la gente con la boca abierta.
context: Noah continues explaining how Slack structures innovation teams to work on new product areas like AI. He emphasizes giving these teams freedom from normal corporate processes and focusing on learning velocity rather than traditional planning cycles. The goal is rapid prototyping and user learning that eventually leads to breakthrough products that exceed customer expectations.
vocabulary_highlights: give them space to run, gel free card, pace of learning, blows people away
topics: Product Management, Leadership & Management, Strategy & Planning

speaker: Noam Lovinsky
text: When you see a team that is motivated, that is building something like they're really excited about, I mean just the inertia, the quality, it's like a whole different game where when you see a team that's sort of down and out and they've really been hitting their head against the wall for a long time, sometimes they just need a change of scene, a change of pace, and they get to a much better situation. So my honest answer is, yeah, it's the, when do you run out of steam is usually the question.
text_ko: 정말 신나서 뭔가를 만들고 있는 팀을 보면 관성(inertia)도 그렇고 결과물의 퀄리티도 완전히 달라요. 반대로 오랫동안 벽에 부딪혀서 기운 빠진 팀은 분위기 자체가 처져 있어서, 그런 팀들은 때로는 단순히 환경이나 속도를 바꿔주는 것만으로도 훨씬 나아져요. 솔직히 말하면 보통은 결국 언제 기운이 다하느냐가 관건이에요.
text_zh: 当你看到一个团队特别有干劲，在做一个他们真正兴奋的项目时，那种势头啊，那个质量啊，完全就是另一个层面的东西。但如果你看到一个团队垂头丧气的，已经撞南墙撞了很久了，有时候他们就是需要换个环境，换个节奏，这样就能进入一个更好的状态。所以我的真心话就是，关键问题通常是，你什么时候会没劲儿了。
text_es: Cuando ves un equipo que está motivado, que está construyendo algo que realmente les emociona, o sea, la inercia, la calidad... es como un juego completamente diferente. Pero cuando ves un equipo que está como decaído y que lleva mucho tiempo dándose contra la pared, a veces lo que necesitan es simplemente cambiar de aires, cambiar el ritmo, y llegan a una situación mucho mejor. Entonces mi respuesta honesta es, sí, se trata de... cuándo se te acaba la gasolina, esa suele ser la pregunta clave.
context: Lenny asks how long you should stick with a project that isn't going well before deciding to move on. Noam explains that while most projects and early companies fail due to lack of stamina rather than running out of money, the key indicator for when to pivot or kill a project is when the team loses motivation and energy. He emphasizes that high-ambiguity projects require tremendous faith and stamina to succeed.
vocabulary_highlights: down and out, hitting their head against the wall, change of scene, run out of steam
topics: Product Management, Leadership & Management, Decision Making

speaker: Noam Lovinsky
text: I think that one important lesson from that is, no one can be a bystander on product strategy. Just because you've got product in your title doesn't mean you're the only one that should be thinking about product strategy certainly at that level. Certainly not in engineering. The CFO, the head of people, everyone needs to have a seat at the table when it comes to product strategy, what the company's doing and what they're going to do to grow out of the situation that they're in.
text_ko: 제가 보기엔 그 일에서 얻은 중요한 교훈 중 하나가 제품 전략(product strategy)에 대해서는 누구도 방관자가 될 수 없다는 거예요. 직함에 '프로덕트'가 들어간다고 해서 그 수준의 제품 전략을 혼자서만 생각해야 한다는 건 절대 아니에요. 특히 엔지니어링 쪽은 더더욱 그렇지 않아요. 최고재무책임자(CFO), 인사 책임자(Head of People) 등 모든 사람이 제품 전략과 회사가 현재 처한 상황에서 벗어나 성장하기 위한 계획에 대해 의사결정 테이블에 함께 있어야 해요.
text_zh: 我觉得这里有个很重要的教训，就是在产品战略(product strategy)这件事上，谁都不能当旁观者。不是说你的职位里带个"产品"两个字，你就是唯一需要考虑产品战略的人，尤其是在那个层面上。工程团队更不用说了。CFO、人事负责人，所有人在讨论产品战略的时候都得有发言权，都得参与进来，讨论公司要做什么，怎么从现在的困境中突围出去。
text_es: Creo que una lección importante de eso es que nadie puede quedarse al margen cuando se trata de estrategia de producto. Que tengas "producto" en tu puesto no significa que seas el único que debe pensar en la estrategia de producto, especialmente a ese nivel. Y menos aún en ingeniería. El CFO, el head de recursos humanos, todos necesitan tener voz y voto cuando hablamos de estrategia de producto, de lo que está haciendo la empresa y de cómo van a salir adelante de la situación en la que están.
context: Lenny asks about lessons from Noam's time at Thumbtack during their turnaround period. Noam explains that when companies face challenges like negative growth, the entire leadership team must unite around product strategy rather than leaving it solely to the product team. He emphasizes that at the leadership level, cross-functional collaboration becomes critical for navigating difficult periods.
vocabulary_highlights: bystander, have a seat at the table
topics: Product Management, Leadership & Management, Strategy & Planning

speaker: Noam Lovinsky
text: If you're a large organization and you do some performance management process twice a year and you're 0 to 1 incubator, you've already killed it. It's the wrong incentive. Smart, good people, even if they're not trying to, they end up kind of gaming things towards the incentive system. And so think long and hard about that.
text_ko: 대규모 조직이고 연 2회 하는 성과 관리 프로세스 (performance management process)를 운영하면서 0에서 1을 만드는 인큐베이터 (0 to 1 incubator) 역할을 하고 있다면 이미 그걸 망쳐버린 거예요. 잘못된 인센티브 구조예요. 똑똑하고 유능한 사람들도 일부러 그러는 게 아니라도 결국 인센티브에 맞춰 시스템을 조작하거나 이득을 보려고 게임하듯 행동하게 돼요 (gaming the system). 그러니까 그 점을 충분히, 진지하게 고민해 보세요.
text_zh: 如果你是个大公司，每年搞两次绩效管理(performance management)，但你做的是从零到一的孵化项目(0 to 1 incubator)，那基本上就死定了。这个激励机制完全搞反了。那些聪明能干的人，哪怕他们不是故意的，最后也会想办法钻激励体系的空子。所以这事儿你得好好想想。
text_es: Si eres una organización grande y haces algún proceso de evaluación de desempeño dos veces al año, pero estás en modo incubadora de 0 a 1, ya la mataste. Es el incentivo equivocado. La gente inteligente y buena, aunque no sea su intención, termina jugando el sistema hacia donde están los incentivos. Así que piénsatelo muy bien.
context: Lenny asks for advice on creating effective startup-within-a-startup initiatives at large companies. Noam discusses the critical importance of designing proper incentive systems for innovation teams. He explains that traditional corporate performance management cycles are fundamentally incompatible with early-stage product development, which requires different timeframes and success metrics than established business operations.
vocabulary_highlights: 0 to 1 incubator, gaming things towards
topics: Product Management, Leadership & Management, Starting a Company

speaker: Noam Lovinsky
text: Growth masks all problems. You don't really have a, I think, true understanding of what is working well and what is not working well when you have incredible growth. And at Thumbtack, it had incredible growth for quite some time, but it was essentially burning through a lot of demand. It was just dropping a lot of demand on the floor because there wasn't sufficient liquidity on the supply side to really meet that demand.
text_ko: 성장은 모든 문제를 가려요. 엄청나게 성장하고 있으면 무엇이 잘되고 있고 무엇이 잘못되고 있는지 진짜로 제대로 알기 어렵거든요. Thumbtack도 한동안 엄청난 성장을 했는데, 사실 많은 수요(demand)를 소진하는 식이었어요. 공급 측면(supply)에 충분한 유동성(liquidity)이 없어서 그 수요를 제대로 충족시키지 못했고, 결국 많은 수요가 그냥 바닥에 떨어져 버렸어요.
text_zh: 增长会掩盖所有问题。我觉得当你有惊人增长的时候，你根本搞不清楚到底哪些地方做得好，哪些地方有问题。Thumbtack有段时间增长确实很猛，但其实是在白白浪费很多需求。因为供给端流动性(supply side liquidity)不够，根本满足不了那么多需求，所以很多需求就这么白白流失了。
text_es: El crecimiento tapa todos los problemas. Cuando tienes un crecimiento increíble, la verdad es que no tienes una idea clara de qué está funcionando bien y qué no. Y en Thumbtack, tuvimos un crecimiento impresionante durante bastante tiempo, pero básicamente estábamos quemando mucha demanda. Se nos estaba cayendo muchísima demanda porque no teníamos suficiente liquidez del lado de la oferta para realmente satisfacer esa demanda.
context: Lenny asks about lessons from Noam's experience at Thumbtack during their challenging period when growth went negative. Noam explains how rapid growth can hide fundamental business problems that only become apparent when growth slows or reverses. At Thumbtack specifically, strong user acquisition was masking supply-side liquidity issues in their marketplace.
vocabulary_highlights: masks all problems, burning through, dropping demand on the floor, sufficient liquidity
topics: Growth & Marketing, Product Management, Strategy & Planning

speaker: Noam Lovinsky
text: I always tell people I feel like I'm an IC trapped in a manager's body sometimes. Fundamentally, I like to build, that's why I do this. I like to make things. And so sometimes the more fun way to make things is to start something and sometimes the better way to make things in the situation that I'm in is to try to support teams and lead through teams.
text_ko: 사람들에게 항상 가끔은 매니저의 몸에 갇힌 개인 기여자(Individual Contributor, IC) 같다고 말해요. 본질적으로 저는 뭔가를 만드는 걸 좋아해서 이 일을 해요. 그래서 때로는 직접 뭔가를 시작해서 만드는 게 더 재밌고, 반대로 지금 제 위치에서는 팀을 지원하고 팀을 통해 이끄는 게 더 나은 방법일 때도 있어요.
text_zh: 我经常跟别人说，有时候感觉自己就像是一个被困在管理者身体里的个人贡献者(IC)。说到底，我就是喜欢搭建东西，这就是我做这行的原因。我喜欢创造。所以有时候创造东西最有意思的方式就是从零开始做一个项目，但有时候在我现在的位置上，更好的创造方式是去支持团队，通过团队来实现目标。
text_es: Siempre le digo a la gente que a veces me siento como un colaborador individual (IC) atrapado en el cuerpo de un gerente. En el fondo, me gusta construir cosas, por eso hago esto. Me gusta crear. Y a veces la forma más divertida de crear es empezar algo desde cero, y otras veces la mejor manera de crear en la situación en la que estoy es tratar de apoyar a los equipos y liderar a través de ellos.
context: Lenny asks about Noam's diverse career experiences across different types of product challenges. Noam explains his motivation for changing roles and companies frequently, describing his core drive to build and create products. An IC refers to an individual contributor - someone who does hands-on work rather than managing others. Noam describes the tension between wanting to build directly versus leading teams to build.
vocabulary_highlights: IC trapped in a manager's body, lead through teams

speaker: Noam Lovinsky
text: When you're thinking about career opportunities and what job to take, it's really, really hard to sniff out really well in a high degree of certainty like success. I think that having a good nose for people and the sort of people that you can be successful with is something that you can develop. What I found is I always try to prioritize putting myself in positions that are going to cause a lot of growth and learning.
text_ko: 커리어 기회나 어떤 직업을 선택할지 고민할 때, 그 일이 정말 성공할지 높은 확률로 잘 가려내는 건 정말 어렵다고 생각해요. 사람을 잘 알아보는 감각, 즉 함께 일했을 때 성공할 수 있는 사람을 판별하는 능력은 충분히 키울 수 있는 거라고 봐요. 저는 항상 성장과 배움을 많이 가져다줄 자리나 상황에 자신을 두는 걸 우선시하려고 해요.
text_zh: 当你在考虑职业机会、选择工作的时候，想要很准确地嗅出成功的机会，真的是特别特别难的。我觉得培养对人的敏锐嗅觉，能看出哪些人可以和你一起成功，这个能力是可以慢慢培养的。我发现我总是会优先把自己放在那些能让我快速成长和学到东西的位置上。
text_es: Cuando estás pensando en oportunidades profesionales y qué trabajo agarrar, es súper difícil detectar con mucha certeza el éxito que vas a tener. Creo que desarrollar buen ojo para la gente y el tipo de personas con las que puedes triunfar es algo que se puede trabajar. Lo que he visto es que siempre trato de priorizarme en posiciones que me van a generar mucho crecimiento y aprendizaje.
context: Lenny asks for general career advice based on Noam's successful journey across multiple companies. Noam explains that while it's difficult to predict which companies or roles will be successful, you can develop skills for evaluating people and teams. He emphasizes choosing roles that will stretch you and create significant personal growth, even when that growth involves discomfort.
vocabulary_highlights: sniff out, good nose for people

speaker: Oji Udezue
text: So I guess while I love mental models, while I love frameworks, what I want people who listen to me and maybe listen to you to understand is you have to go deeper. Because as situations change, as an investor and advisor to startups, I advise differently if you are just starting, if you're in the middle, and if you're scaling. In the book that I'm writing on product, I actually make that distinction a lot in the book, which stage are you?
text_ko: 사고 모델(mental models)도 좋아하고 프레임워크(frameworks)도 좋아하긴 한데, 제 얘기를 듣는 분들—그리고 아마 당신의 청중들도—에게 꼭 전하고 싶은 건 한 단계 더 깊이 들어가야 한다는 거예요. 상황이 바뀌면 접근도 달라지거든요. 저는 스타트업(startups)에 투자자이자 조언자로서, 막 시작하는 단계인지, 한창 진행 중인지, 확장 단계(scaling)인지에 따라 조언을 다르게 해요. 제가 지금 쓰고 있는 제품(product) 관련 책에서도 그걸 자주 구분해서 다루고 있어요 — 당신은 지금 어느 단계인가요?
text_zh: 所以虽然我很喜欢心智模型(mental models)，也很喜欢各种框架，但我希望听我们说话的人能明白一点——你得往深了挖。因为情况在变，作为投资人和创业顾问，我给刚起步的公司、发展中的公司，还有在扩张期的公司，建议都不一样。我正在写的这本产品书里，其实经常会提到这个区别——你现在处在哪个阶段？
text_es: Mira, aunque me encantan los modelos mentales, aunque me encantan los frameworks, lo que quiero que entienda la gente que me escucha y que tal vez te escucha a ti es que tienen que profundizar más. Porque conforme van cambiando las situaciones, como inversionista y asesor de startups, yo asesoro de manera diferente si apenas estás empezando, si estás en la mitad del proceso, o si ya estás escalando. En el libro que estoy escribiendo sobre producto, de hecho hago mucho esa distinción en el libro: ¿en qué etapa te encuentras?
context: Lenny asks Oji about his perspective on frameworks broadly after noting that Oji had an interesting response when asked about frameworks. Oji explains that while he appreciates frameworks and mental models as shortcuts for dense thinking, he believes product managers need to understand the fundamentals behind frameworks rather than applying them blindly. He emphasizes that product management isn't a science and involves significant uncertainty, so practitioners must adapt frameworks to their specific stage and situation.
vocabulary_highlights: make that distinction, go deeper, just starting, in the middle
topics: Product Management, Strategy & Planning, Learning & Growth

speaker: Oji Udezue
text: Frequent is every day really or multiple times a week. Infrequent starts to be like two times a week, once a month. And of course there's a big interregnum in the middle of that.
text_ko: 빈번하다는 건 보통 매일이거나 주에 여러 번을 말해요. 드문 편은 주에 두 번 정도나 한 달에 한 번쯤부터예요. 그리고 그 중간에는 큰 공백기(interregnum)가 있죠.
text_zh: 高频用户其实就是每天都用，或者一周用好几次的。低频用户呢，大概是一周用两次，或者一个月用一次这样。当然了，中间还有很大一块空白地带。
text_es: Frecuente significa realmente todos los días o varias veces por semana. Lo poco frecuente ya empieza a ser como dos veces por semana, una vez al mes. Y claro, hay un gran vacío en el medio de todo eso.
context: Lenny asks Oji to clarify what constitutes 'frequent' in his framework for finding big B2B SaaS opportunities. Oji had previously explained his framework that segments workflows by how many departments they affect (everyone vs niche) and how frequently they're executed. This response defines the frequency dimension of his framework, explaining that truly frequent workflows happen daily or multiple times per week, while infrequent ones might be twice weekly or monthly.
vocabulary_highlights: big interregnum
topics: Product Management, Starting a Company, Strategy & Planning

speaker: Oji Udezue
text: The sharp problem is a little bit of that whole quadrant framework, which is what problem are you going to work on? I think that problems have predictive power of success if you actually solve the problem. And this is different from, I have an idea, yeah. I think that a lot of innovation can come from inspiration, but the best inspiration comes from understanding customers and their problems.
text_ko: 핵심 문제는 그 사분면 프레임워크(quadrant framework)에서 ‘어떤 문제를 다룰 것인가’를 정하는 한 부분이에요. 제가 보기엔, 문제를 실제로 해결하면 그 문제 자체가 성공 가능성을 예측해주는 힘이 있어요. 단순히 ‘아이디어가 있다’는 것과는 다른 얘기죠. 영감에서 많은 혁신(innovation)이 나오긴 하지만, 최고의 영감은 고객과 그들의 문제를 이해할 때 온다고 생각해요.
