text_zh: 关键问题其实就是那个四象限框架(quadrant framework)的一部分，就是你要解决什么问题？我觉得如果你真的能解决这个问题，那这个问题本身就能预测你会不会成功。这跟"我有个想法"是完全不一样的。我认为很多创新都可以从灵感中来，但最好的灵感其实是来自于对客户和他们痛点的深度理解。
text_es: El tema clave está en ese marco de cuadrantes, ¿no? O sea, ¿en qué problema te vas a enfocar realmente? Yo creo que los problemas tienen un poder predictivo del éxito si de verdad logras resolverlos. Y esto es muy diferente a decir "se me ocurrió una idea", ¿me entiendes? Pienso que mucha innovación puede venir de la inspiración, pero la mejor inspiración surge cuando realmente entiendes a tus clientes y sus problemas.
context: Lenny asks Oji about his concept of starting with a 'sharp problem' in PLG product development. Oji explains that focusing on sharp problems - those that materially steal customers' time, energy, money, or focus - has predictive power for startup success. He distinguishes between having an idea versus identifying a genuinely painful problem that customers desperately want solved, emphasizing that the best innovation comes from deep customer problem understanding rather than just inspiration.
vocabulary_highlights: predictive power, comes from inspiration
topics: Product Management, Starting a Company, Strategy & Planning

speaker: Oji Udezue
text: When you see people's eyes get big and they expose more whites to you, you're probably onto something. It's not enough, that's not a workflow thing, that's an excitement thing. But people often react that way when you're solving a really sharp problem for them. And then people spontaneously bring up money, it's like when can I pay?
text_ko: 사람들 눈이 커지고 흰자가 더 보일 정도면, 뭔가 제대로 건드린 거예요. 그 자체만으로는 충분하진 않아요 — 워크플로(workflow) 문제가 아니라 사람들의 흥분의 문제죠. 보통 정말 핵심적인 문제를 해결해줄 때 사람들이 그렇게 반응해요. 그러다 보면 사람들이 스스로 돈 얘기를 꺼내요. “언제 결제하면 되죠?” 이런 식으로요.
text_zh: 当你看到别人眼睛瞪得老大，露出更多眼白的时候，说明你可能找对路子了。光这样还不够，这不是什么工作流程的问题，这是兴奋劲儿上来了。但是当你真正帮他们解决了一个很棘手的问题时，人们经常会有这种反应。然后他们就会主动提到钱的事儿，就像"我什么时候能付钱？"
text_es: Cuando veas que a la gente se le abren los ojos como platos y se quedan así, probablemente has dado en el clavo. No es suficiente, eso no es cosa del proceso de trabajo, es pura emoción. Pero la gente suele reaccionar así cuando les estás resolviendo un problema que realmente les duele. Y entonces empiezan a sacar el tema del dinero por sí solos, te dicen "¿cuándo puedo pagarte?"
context: Lenny asks Oji about signs that indicate you've identified a sharp enough problem for your product. Oji explains his 'whites of their eyes' concept - when you present a problem to potential customers and see their eyes widen with excitement, exposing more of the whites of their eyes. He describes this physical reaction as a strong indicator that you're addressing a genuinely painful problem, especially when customers spontaneously start discussing payment or urgency around getting access to your solution.
vocabulary_highlights: whites of their eyes, onto something, spontaneously bring up
topics: Product Management, Starting a Company, Decision Making

speaker: Oji Udezue
text: One of the big, hairy, audacious goals of product management is being able to process these signals efficiently. We did it in a certain way at Calendly, which I drew a rig together through workflows and Slack, and then having individuals triage those things.
text_ko: 프로덕트 매니지먼트(product management)에서 거대하고 대담한 목표 중 하나는 이런 신호(signals)를 효율적으로 처리할 수 있게 되는 거예요. 캘린들리(Calendly)에선 제가 워크플로(workflows)와 슬랙(Slack)을 엮어 하나의 구성(rig)을 만들고, 사람들이 그 항목들을 트리아지(triage)하도록 했어요.
text_zh: 产品管理的一个超级大胆的目标就是能够高效地处理这些信号。我们在Calendly是这么做的，我把工作流程和Slack整合在一起搭了个系统，然后让团队成员去分类处理这些事情。
text_es: Uno de los objetivos más ambiciosos y desafiantes del product management es poder procesar estas señales de manera eficiente. En Calendly lo hicimos de una forma particular - armé un sistema combinando workflows y Slack, y luego tuvimos gente encargada de priorizar y clasificar todo eso.
context: Oji is explaining his concept of 'customer listening' - systematically processing customer signals that happen naturally through social media, app stores, support tickets, NPS surveys, and sales data. He distinguishes this from customer discovery, describing it as capturing feedback that customers are already providing whether you're listening or not. He explains that efficiently processing these signals is a major challenge in product management, requiring systematic workflows to triage and act on customer feedback.
vocabulary_highlights: big, hairy, audacious goals, drew a rig together, triage those things
topics: Product Management, Coaching & Development, Strategy & Planning

speaker: Oji Udezue
text: Virality is really when the word of mouth of a product is high quality. That's really the essence of it. Let me rephrase that. It's when customers market your product. And that is incredibly powerful, but also that's incredibly actionable, if that makes sense.
text_ko: 바이럴성(virality)은 제품에 대한 입소문이 질적으로 뛰어날 때예요. 그게 바로 핵심이에요. 다시 말하면 고객들이 스스로 제품을 마케팅해 줄 때라는 뜻이에요. 그건 굉장히 강력하고, 동시에 실행 가능한 것이기도 해요, 이해되시죠?
text_zh: 病毒式传播(virality)其实就是产品的口碑特别好。这就是核心所在。让我换个说法吧。就是客户主动帮你推广产品。这个力量非常强大，关键是也很好操作，你明白我的意思吧。
text_es: La viralidad es básicamente cuando el boca a boca de un producto es de muy buena calidad. Esa es la esencia del asunto. Déjame decirlo de otra manera. Es cuando tus propios clientes se encargan de promocionar tu producto. Y eso es súper poderoso, pero también es algo muy concreto en lo que puedes trabajar, ¿me explico?
context: Lenny asks Oji about tactics for increasing product virality, especially for B2B products. Oji starts by redefining virality, explaining that many people misunderstand it as synthetic tactics like referral programs. He defines true virality as high-quality word of mouth where customers naturally market your product for you. He emphasizes this definition is actionable because it focuses on building something customers genuinely want to share rather than relying on artificial viral mechanisms.
vocabulary_highlights: high quality, incredibly actionable

speaker: Oji Udezue
text: Forest time is the idea that you make time within your week, within your month to see the forest for the trees. Most of the time when you're operating, you're seeing the tree, which is the problem in front of you. But sometimes you need to see the forest, so you can figure out it as an alternate path, different from the one that you are currently on your campaign.
text_ko: 숲을 보는 시간(forest time)은 일주일이나 한 달 단위로 잠깐 시간을 내 전체를 바라보는 시간을 만드는 아이디어예요. 보통 운영할 때는 눈앞의 문제, 즉 한 그루의 나무만 보게 되지만, 가끔은 숲 전체를 봐야 지금 진행 중인 캠페인(campaign)과는 다른 대안 경로를 찾아낼 수 있어요.
text_zh: 森林时间(Forest time)就是说，你要在每周或每月专门抽出时间来看大局。平时我们忙起来的时候，眼里只有眼前这棵树，也就是手头的问题。但有时候你得跳出来看整片森林，这样才能发现别的路子，而不是一直埋头走现在这条路。
text_es: El "tiempo de bosque" (forest time) es la idea de que te reserves tiempo durante la semana, durante el mes, para ver el panorama completo. La mayoría del tiempo cuando estás operando, solo ves el árbol, que es el problema que tienes enfrente. Pero a veces necesitas ver todo el bosque para darte cuenta de que hay un camino alternativo, diferente al que estás siguiendo actualmente en tu campaña.
context: Lenny asks Oji to explain his concept of 'forest time' that he wrote about in a post. Oji explains that when you're operating day-to-day in a company, you get caught up in immediate problems (seeing the trees) and lose the bigger picture perspective (seeing the forest). Forest time is intentionally scheduled time - like a day per month - to step back and gain a bird's eye view of your situation, identify alternative paths, and improve your strategic aim before executing further.
vocabulary_highlights: see the forest for the trees, alternate path, on your campaign
topics: Leadership & Management, Strategy & Planning, Work-Life Balance

speaker: Paige Costello
text: The thing I would say is bring the insight. Know thy customer. Know thy market. Know thy competitors. Know thy numbers. Know thy product. If you can be the person in the room who has watched customers use the product and has a point of view about why one tool is significantly better or worse in a given dimension, and you can do that with confidence and clarity, and you don't need to know the other person's functional domain, and you don't need the expertise in what they're experts at, you can bring insight that makes people curious, and trust you, and just immediately believe that there's an opportunity that you're not advocating for that just is true.
text_ko: 제가 드리고 싶은 말은 인사이트(insight)를 가져오라는 거예요. 고객을 알아야 해요. 시장을 알아야 해요. 경쟁자를 알아야 해요. 숫자를 알아야 해요. 제품(product)을 알아야 해요. 만약 그 자리에서 고객이 제품을 쓰는 모습을 직접 지켜봤고, 특정 툴(tool)이 어떤 차원(dimension)에서 훨씬 낫거나 못한지에 대해 자신 있고 명확한 관점(point of view)을 말할 수 있는 사람이라면, 상대방의 기능 영역(functional domain)을 알 필요도 없고 그들이 전문인 분야의 전문성(expertise)을 알 필요도 없어요. 그런 사람은 사람들로 하여금 호기심을 갖게 하고 당신을 신뢰하게 만들며, 당신이 굳이 밀어붙이지 않아도 그 기회(opportunity)가 분명히 존재한다고 바로 믿게 만들 수 있어요.
text_zh: 我想说的就是，你得带着洞察力来。要了解你的客户，了解你的市场，了解你的竞争对手，了解你的数据，了解你的产品。如果你能成为房间里那个真正观察过客户怎么使用产品的人，能说出为什么某个工具在某个方面明显更好或更差，而且你说得很有底气很清楚，这时候你不需要懂别人专业领域的东西，不需要在他们擅长的地方也成为专家，你照样能提供让人眼前一亮的洞察，让大家对你产生好奇心，信任你，马上就相信确实存在这样一个机会——而且你不是在推销什么，这就是事实。
text_es: Lo que yo diría es: trae perspectiva a la mesa. Conoce a tu cliente a fondo. Conoce tu mercado. Conoce a tu competencia. Conoce tus números. Conoce tu producto. Si puedes ser esa persona en la sala que realmente ha visto cómo los clientes usan el producto y tiene una opinión fundamentada sobre por qué una herramienta es significativamente mejor o peor en cierto aspecto, y puedes comunicarlo con confianza y claridad, no necesitas dominar el área funcional de la otra persona ni ser experto en lo suyo. Puedes aportar esa perspectiva que despierta curiosidad en la gente, que genera confianza, y que inmediatamente les hace ver que hay una oportunidad real que no estás tratando de vender, sino que simplemente existe.
context: Lenny asks Paige what she's learned about how to garner trust and win over skeptics, especially when she's often the youngest person in the room leading people with decades more experience. Paige explains that instead of trying to pretend you have more experience than you do, the key is to become the expert on customer insights, market knowledge, and product understanding. She emphasizes that bringing valuable insights to every meeting is what builds credibility and trust, not trying to match others' functional expertise.
vocabulary_highlights: bring the insight, know thy, functional domain, makes people curious

speaker: Paige Costello
text: Your brain is so accustomed to having a scarcity mindset as opposed to creating alternative options or seeing a different path. Effectively, there's this notion of, "How might the opposite be true?" The moment I challenged myself and said, "How might the opposite be true?" my shoulders dropped. I felt more relaxed. I was like, "Oh, yeah, I can do both. It will be fine."
text_ko: 우리의 뇌는 대안을 만들거나 다른 길을 찾아보는 대신, 결핍 마인드셋(scarcity mindset)에 너무 익숙해져 있어요. 사실 핵심은 '반대가 어떻게 사실일 수 있을까?'라는 질문을 해보는 거예요. 제가 그 질문을 스스로에게 던졌을 때 어깨가 확 내려가고 훨씬 편안해졌어요. '아, 저도 둘 다 할 수 있겠네. 괜찮을 거예요.'라고 느꼈어요.
text_zh: 你的大脑已经习惯了匮乏思维(scarcity mindset)，而不是去想其他的选择或者看到不同的路径。其实有这样一个概念："反过来想会怎样？"当我开始挑战自己，问自己"反过来想会怎样？"的时候，我整个人都放松下来了。肩膀也不那么紧绷了，感觉轻松多了。我就想，"哦对啊，我完全可以两个都做，没什么大不了的。"
text_es: Tu cerebro está tan acostumbrado a tener una mentalidad de escasez en lugar de crear alternativas o ver un camino diferente. En realidad, existe esta idea de "¿Cómo podría ser cierto lo contrario?" En el momento que me desafié y me dije "¿Cómo podría ser cierto lo contrario?" se me relajaron los hombros. Me sentí más tranquilo. Fue como "Ah, sí, puedo hacer ambas cosas. Va a estar bien."
context: Lenny asks what Paige finds most holds back new product managers. Paige explains that new PMs often get stuck in a scarcity mindset where they see only limited options or think they have to choose between competing priorities. She shares a personal technique of asking "How might the opposite be true?" to challenge these mental constraints and find creative solutions that allow for multiple paths forward rather than false trade-offs.
vocabulary_highlights: scarcity mindset, How might the opposite be true, my shoulders dropped
topics: Product Management, Decision Making, Learning & Growth

speaker: Paige Costello
text: When you take a new role, become best friends with a researcher, and spend time watching customers use the product firsthand because what they maybe report on or are trying to do a study about might be very different from what you observe, but you really just need that front row seat with customers. It's amazing how little you have to do to quickly catch up to understanding who the organization is solving for well and poorly, and how people really use your product versus how your teams use your product, especially in organizations where there are heavy dogfooding cultures.
text_ko: 새 역할을 맡으면 연구자와 친해지고 고객이 제품을 쓰는 모습을 현장에서 직접 오래 지켜보세요. 고객들이 보고하는 것이나 연구에서 다루려는 내용과 실제 관찰되는 건 꽤 다를 수 있거든요. 결국 고객 곁에서 직접 보는 앞줄 자리가 필요해요. 그러면 조직이 누구를 잘 도와주고 못 도와주는지, 사람들이 제품을 실제로 어떻게 쓰는지와 팀들이 내부적으로 쓰는 방식의 차이를 빠르게 파악하는 데 생각보다 많은 노력이 들지 않는다는 걸 금방 알게 될 거예요. 특히 도그푸딩 문화(dogfooding culture)가 강한 조직일수록 그 차이는 더 큽니다.
text_zh: 刚到新岗位的时候，一定要跟研究员搞好关系，多花时间直接观察用户怎么用产品，因为他们汇报的内容或者研究的东西，可能跟你实际看到的完全不一样。你真的需要跟用户面对面接触。其实你不用做太多，就能很快搞清楚公司到底为哪些用户解决得好，哪些解决得不好，还有用户真实的使用习惯跟你们团队内部的使用习惯差别有多大，特别是那些很喜欢内部试用产品(dogfooding)的公司。
text_es: Cuando agarres un puesto nuevo, hazte súper amigo de alguien de investigación y dedica tiempo a ver de primera mano cómo los clientes usan el producto, porque lo que tal vez reporten o lo que estén tratando de estudiar puede ser muy diferente de lo que tú observes. Pero de verdad necesitas ese asiento en primera fila con los clientes. Es increíble lo poco que tienes que hacer para ponerte al día rápido y entender para quién está resolviendo bien la organización y para quién mal, y cómo la gente realmente usa tu producto versus cómo lo usan tus equipos, especialmente en organizaciones donde hay mucha cultura de dogfooding.
context: Lenny asks how to gain the customer insights needed to build trust and credibility as a product manager. Paige emphasizes the importance of directly observing customers using your product rather than relying solely on research reports. She warns that in companies with strong internal usage cultures (dogfooding), teams can become disconnected from how real customers actually behave, making firsthand customer observation even more critical for product success.
vocabulary_highlights: become best friends with, front row seat, heavy dogfooding cultures

speaker: Paige Costello
text: Always answer the question that they should have asked. I was pretty surprised by that advice because it was very profound in the moment because I think when you're a student and you are accustomed... If you're an achiever, you like to get As. You're probably going to hear a question and answer it. But what I learned from that was that there's actually another altitude, another point of strategy when you're in a meeting or in a conversation to make sure that you're covering the more important point, the bigger picture, the alternative that the person asking the question maybe didn't see or consider.
text_ko: 항상 상대가 물어봤어야 할 질문에 답해 주세요. 그 말을 듣고 좀 놀랐어요 — 그 순간에는 꽤 깊게 와닿았거든요. 학생 시절, 성적(A)을 잘 받는 데 익숙한 사람이라면 질문을 들으면 그냥 그 질문에 답하는 습관이 있잖아요. 하지만 제가 거기서 배운 건, 회의나 대화에서는 사실 한 단계 위의 관점, 즉 다른 전략적 포인트(point of strategy)를 갖고 더 중요한 쟁점이나 큰 그림(big picture), 질문한 사람이 보지 못했거나 고려하지 않았을지도 모르는 대안까지 챙겨야 한다는 거예요.
text_zh: 要回答他们本来应该问的问题。当时听到这个建议我挺意外的，因为那一刻感觉特别有道理。我觉得当你还是学生的时候，你已经习惯了...如果你是那种追求优秀的人，喜欢拿A，你可能听到问题就直接回答了。但我从中学到的是，其实还有另一个层面，另一种策略思维——在开会或者聊天的时候，要确保你说的是更重要的点，更大的格局，或者是提问的人可能没看到或者没考虑到的其他可能性。
text_es: Siempre responde la pregunta que realmente deberían haber hecho. Me sorprendió bastante ese consejo porque fue muy profundo en ese momento, porque creo que cuando eres estudiante y estás acostumbrado... Si eres de los que siempre busca destacar, te gusta sacar buenas notas. Probablemente vas a escuchar una pregunta y la contestas tal como te la hicieron. Pero lo que aprendí de eso es que en realidad hay otro nivel, otro punto estratégico cuando estás en una junta o en una conversación: asegurarte de que estás cubriendo el punto más importante, el panorama general, la alternativa que quizás la persona que hizo la pregunta no vio o no consideró.
context: Paige shares a piece of advice she received from a business unit leader at Intuit after a high-stakes product review. The leader told her to "always answer the question they should have asked." Paige explains how this advice helped her understand that there's a strategic level beyond just directly answering what's asked - it's about addressing the broader context, bigger picture, or alternatives that the questioner might not have considered.
vocabulary_highlights: another altitude, another point of strategy
topics: Communication Skills, Strategy & Planning, Leadership & Management

speaker: Paige Costello
text: I would say this illusion that you have to be all-knowing and super confident sets you up to be in a place of advocacy instead of inquiry. So PMs who are newer in their careers or who are in a different space than they're accustomed to working really want to be pro really fast. What pro means is trying to cut that straight path, and that can reduce information and conversation that makes you smarter.
text_ko: 제가 보기엔 '모든 걸 다 알고 완전 자신감 있어야 해'라는 착각이 오히려 당신을 탐구(inquiry) 대신 옹호(advocacy)의 위치에 놓이게 해요. 그래서 경력이 짧은 PM들(Product Managers)이나 익숙한 분야가 아닌 다른 영역에서 일하는 사람들은 빨리 프로(pro)가 되고 싶어해요. 그런데 '프로'라는 건 보통 바로 그 지름길을 택하려는 거고, 그게 오히려 당신을 더 똑똑하게 만들어 줄 정보나 대화를 줄여버릴 수 있어요.
text_zh: 我觉得这种认为自己必须什么都懂、超级自信的错觉，会让你变成只会争辩而不会提问的人。所以那些刚入行的产品经理(PM)，或者是刚换到不熟悉领域的PM，都特别想快速变成专家。但是所谓的专家就是想走捷径，这样反而会错过很多让你变聪明的信息和讨论机会。
text_es: Yo diría que esa ilusión de que tienes que saberlo todo y ser súper seguro te lleva a ponerte en modo defensa en lugar de estar preguntando y aprendiendo. Entonces los PMs que están empezando en sus carreras o que están en un área diferente a la que están acostumbrados, realmente quieren verse como profesionales muy rápido. Y ser "pro" significa tratar de ir directo al grano, pero eso puede limitar la información y las conversaciones que te hacen más inteligente.
context: Lenny asks what most holds back new product managers from being successful. Paige identifies a key problem where new PMs feel pressure to appear expert and confident immediately, which leads them to advocate for solutions rather than ask questions. She explains that trying to "be pro" by taking the most direct path actually limits the learning and collaboration that would make them more effective product managers.
vocabulary_highlights: place of advocacy instead of inquiry, want to be pro really fast, cut that straight path
topics: Product Management, Career Development, Learning & Growth

speaker: Paige Costello
text: I would go to my meetings with a stack of Post-Its, and I would write what I wish I was saying on Post-Its and see if someone else would say it first. Then, if by the end of the meeting, I had decided that I still had a Post-It or two that was worthwhile, I would say them. But you've got to police yourself because no one else will do it because no matter how accessible you think you are, other people know that you're the boss.
text_ko: 회의에 포스트잇(Post-its)을 잔뜩 들고 가서, 하고 싶었던 말들을 포스트잇에 적어놔서 누가 먼저 그 말을 하는지 지켜봤어요. 회의가 끝날 때까지도 그중 한두 장이 쓸 만하다고 판단되면 제가 그때 꺼내 말했죠. 다만 스스로를 잘 통제해야 해요. 다른 사람이 대신해주지 않으니까요 — 아무리 친근하게 보여도 사람들은 당신이 상사라는 걸 알거든요.
text_zh: 我开会的时候会带一摞便利贴，把想说的话先写在上面，看看会不会有别人先说出来。如果到会议结束时，我觉得手里还有一两张便利贴上的内容值得说，我才会开口。但你得自己管住自己，因为没人会替你做这件事——不管你觉得自己多么平易近人，别人心里都清楚你是老板。
text_es: Yo iba a las reuniones con un montón de Post-Its, y escribía lo que quería decir en los papelitos para ver si alguien más lo decía primero. Entonces, si al final de la reunión todavía tenía uno o dos Post-Its que valían la pena, los decía. Pero tienes que controlarte solo porque nadie más lo va a hacer - no importa qué tan accesible te creas, los demás saben que tú eres el jefe.
context: Paige shares a mistake she made when transitioning from individual contributor to manager - the challenge of giving guidance without micromanaging. She describes a technique she developed using Post-It notes to control her impulse to immediately share her thoughts in meetings. By writing down what she wanted to say and waiting to see if others would contribute first, she learned to create space for her team to speak up while still ensuring important points got covered.
vocabulary_highlights: police yourself, no matter how accessible you think you are

speaker: Patrick Campbell
text: The bratty thing here is that real professional ship. At the end of the day, real... I don't care if you're a marketer or a product person, engineer, ops person, people ops, real professional ship, and they ship at a pretty high frequency for whatever they're doing. In my opinion, your tempo framework is more important than your org design.
text_ko: 약간 건방지게 들릴 수 있는데, 핵심은 진짜 프로는 출시(ship)를 한다는 거예요. 결국엔 마케터든 제품 담당자든 엔지니어든 운영 담당자든 피플 오퍼레이션(people ops)이든 상관없이, 진짜 프로는 자기 일이 무엇이든 꽤 높은 빈도로 출시(ship)를 해요. 제 생각엔 템포 프레임워크(tempo framework)가 조직 설계(org design)보다 더 중요해요.
text_zh: 这里最关键的一点就是，真正的专业人士都能交付成果。说到底，不管你是做市场的、产品的、工程师、运营，还是人事运营，真正专业的人都能持续交付，而且频率还挺高的。在我看来，你的节奏框架(tempo framework)比组织架构设计更重要。
text_es: Lo que me molesta aquí es esa mentalidad de entregar trabajo profesional de verdad. Al final del día, los profesionales de verdad... me da igual si eres de marketing, de producto, ingeniero, de operaciones, de recursos humanos, los profesionales de verdad entregan resultados, y lo hacen con bastante frecuencia en lo que sea que estén haciendo. En mi opinión, tu ritmo de trabajo es más importante que cómo tengas estructurada la organización.
context: Lenny asks Patrick about shipping and what mistakes people make when trying to ship faster. Patrick explains that real professionals ship consistently and at high frequency, regardless of their role. He argues that having a clear tempo framework - understanding what good looks like in terms of shipping cadence - is more crucial than organizational structure for creating productive teams.
vocabulary_highlights: bratty thing, real professional ship, tempo framework, org design

speaker: Patrick Campbell
text: The basic idea is bootstrapping is for lifestyle businesses that want to cash flow. Funding is for companies trying to create a billion dollars in annual revenue. And that answer offends everybody. That answer offends the indie friends I have, they're going to be like, "Oh, what about Basecamp [inaudible 00:12:43], ProfitWell?"
text_ko: 기본적으로 부트스트래핑(bootstrapping)은 현금흐름(cash flow)을 원하느 라이프스타일 비즈니스(lifestyle businesses)를 위한 거예요. 펀딩(funding)은 연매출 10억 달러(billion dollars in annual revenue)를 만들려는 회사들을 위한 거고요. 이 말은 사람들 기분을 상하게 해요. 제 인디(indie) 친구들은 ‘그럼 Basecamp나 ProfitWell은요?’ 하고 반발할 거예요.
text_zh: 基本思路就是这样的：自力更生(bootstrapping)适合那些想要现金流的生活方式企业。而融资呢，是给那些想创造年收入十亿美金的公司用的。这个答案得罪所有人。我那些做独立开发的朋友肯定不爽，他们会说："那Basecamp怎么说？还有ProfitWell呢？"
text_es: La idea básica es que el bootstrapping es para negocios de estilo de vida que quieren generar flujo de caja. El financiamiento externo es para empresas que buscan crear mil millones de dólares en ingresos anuales. Y esa respuesta ofende a todo el mundo. Esa respuesta ofende a mis amigos indie, van a decir "Oye, ¿y qué pasa con Basecamp [inaudible 00:12:43], ProfitWell?"
context: Lenny asks Patrick about bootstrapping since he successfully bootstrapped and sold ProfitWell for over $200 million without any funding. Patrick gives his contrarian hot take on when to bootstrap versus raise funding. He believes bootstrapping works best for businesses focused on cash flow, while venture funding is better suited for companies targeting billion-dollar revenue goals.
vocabulary_highlights: cash flow, offends everybody, indie friends

speaker: Patrick Campbell
text: The number one thing to figure out when you're thinking about the different pricing pieces, pound for pound, it's the pricing metric or the value metric. That's how you charge per user, per thousand visits, per thousand what's its, whatever it is.
text_ko: 가격의 여러 요소를 고민할 때 무엇보다 중요한 건 바로 가격 지표(pricing metric), 즉 가치 지표(value metric)예요. 그게 사용자당, 방문 천 건당 같은 어떤 단위로 과금할지 정하는 기준이거든요.
text_zh: 在考虑定价策略的时候，最关键的一点就是要搞清楚定价指标(pricing metric)或者说价值指标(value metric)。就是说你按什么来收费——按用户数、按千次访问量、按千次什么的，反正就是按什么单位来计费。
text_es: Lo más importante que tienes que definir cuando estás pensando en los diferentes elementos de precios, sin duda alguna, es la métrica de precio o la métrica de valor (value metric). O sea, cómo vas a cobrar: por usuario, por mil visitas, por mil lo que sea, da igual lo que uses.
context: Lenny asks Patrick about pricing strategy and where founders should focus their efforts for maximum impact. Patrick, being one of the top experts on SaaS pricing, explains that the most important element to get right is the value metric - how you actually charge customers. This is the foundation that makes everything else in pricing work better, from acquisition to retention.
vocabulary_highlights: pound for pound, pricing metric, value metric

speaker: Patrick Campbell
text: Strategic retention is all the stuff that you as a great product leader, a great product team are doing. Your ICPs, your time to value, road mapping, the right features, figuring out your mission metric, agonizing over every little thing, all the paper cuts of being a great product leader. But because you're so focused and so biased towards that, you miss out typically on this thing we call tactical retention.
text_ko: 전략적 리텐션(strategic retention)은 훌륭한 제품 리더로서, 훌륭한 제품 팀으로서 하는 모든 일들이에요. 이상적 고객 프로필(ICP), 가치 실현 시간(time to value), 로드맵 작성(road mapping), 적절한 기능 선정, 미션 메트릭(mission metric) 찾아내기, 사소한 것까지 신경 쓰며 괴로워하는—제품 리더로서 겪는 자잘한 문제들(paper cuts) 같은 것들이요. 그런데 거기에만 너무 집중하고 편향되다 보면 보통 우리가 전술적 리텐션(tactical retention)이라고 부르는 걸 놓치게 되는 경우가 많아요.
text_zh: 战略留存就是你们作为优秀产品负责人和产品团队在做的所有事情。你们的ICP(理想客户画像)，缩短价值实现时间，产品路线图规划，做对的功能，找准你们的核心指标，为每个细节抠破头，这些都是优秀产品负责人要承受的各种折磨。但正因为你们太专注于这些，有了思维定式，往往就会错过我们说的战术留存这一块。
text_es: La retención estratégica es todo lo que tú como líder de producto increíble, como equipo de producto increíble, están haciendo. Tus ICPs, tu tiempo de valor (time to value), el mapeo de ruta (road mapping), las funcionalidades correctas, definir tu métrica de misión (mission metric), preocuparte por cada detallito, todas esas pequeñas molestias de ser un gran líder de producto. Pero como estás tan enfocado y tan sesgado hacia eso, típicamente te pierdes esta cosa que llamamos retención táctica.
context: Lenny asks Patrick about retention strategies, another area where Patrick is a recognized expert. Patrick explains there are two types of retention that companies need to focus on. Strategic retention involves all the product work that product teams naturally focus on, while tactical retention covers operational issues like payment failures and cancellation flows that often get overlooked but represent 25-40% of churn problems.
vocabulary_highlights: strategic retention, agonizing over, paper cuts, tactical retention

speaker: Patrick Campbell
text: In my opinion, your tempo framework is more important than your org design. And so if you've ever had a team that seems really, really smart, but they're always planning or they don't really ship a lot, or you've had trouble where everyone kind of gets it at the leadership level, but then the team below them and below them seems to be kind of going in a different direction, you probably don't have enough alignment and you don't have enough alignment on what good looks like in terms of tempo.
text_ko: 제 생각에는 템포 프레임워크(tempo framework)가 조직 설계(org design)보다 더 중요해요. 그래서 만약 정말 똑똑해 보이는 팀이 있는데 항상 계획만 하고 실제로는 자주 결과물을 내지 못하거나, 리더십 레벨에서는 다들 이해하는 것 같은데 그 아래 팀들이 어딘가 다른 방향으로 움직인다면, 아마 충분한 정렬(alignment)이 안 돼 있는 거고 특히 템포 관점에서 무엇이 '잘하는 모습'인지에 대한 공감대가 부족한 거예요.
text_zh: 我觉得吧，节奏框架(tempo framework)比组织架构设计更重要。你肯定遇到过这种情况：有些团队看起来特别聪明，但总是在那儿规划规划的，实际出活儿不多；或者领导层都挺明白的，但下面的人、再下面的人，好像都在各干各的，方向不太一致。这种情况多半是大家没有达成共识，特别是在节奏把控上，什么叫"做得好"，大家心里都没个准儿。
text_es: En mi opinión, tu marco de ritmo de trabajo es más importante que el diseño organizacional. Entonces, si alguna vez has tenido un equipo que parece súper inteligente, pero siempre están planeando o no entregan mucho, o has tenido problemas donde todos los líderes lo entienden, pero después el equipo que está debajo de ellos y así sucesivamente parece ir en otra dirección, probablemente no tienes suficiente alineación y no tienes suficiente alineación sobre cómo se ve un buen ritmo de trabajo.
context: Lenny asks Patrick about shipping and building productive teams. Patrick shares his framework for creating high-output teams by establishing clear tempo expectations. He explains that many smart teams fail to ship effectively not because of organizational structure, but because they lack alignment on what good performance looks like in terms of shipping frequency and output expectations.
vocabulary_highlights: tempo framework, org design, seems to be kind of going in a different direction

speaker: Patrick Campbell
text: Everything in your business, it does not matter what type of business you have, everything is used to drive someone to a point of conversion or justify the product or the price that you're offering up. That customer is a human being you're driving to that point of conversion and it's your job to understand how they perceive you, how they perceive their problem, how they perceive the world around them, around your products.
text_ko: 어떤 비즈니스를 운영하든 상관없이, 비즈니스의 모든 요소는 결국 누군가를 구매 같은 전환 지점(conversion)으로 이끌거나, 당신이 제시하는 제품이나 가격을 납득시키는 데 쓰여요. 그 고객은 결국 한 사람이고, 당신의 역할은 그들이 당신을 어떻게 인식하는지, 자신의 문제를 어떻게 바라보는지, 그리고 당신의 제품을 둘러싼 세상을 어떻게 생각하는지를 이해하는 거예요.
text_zh: 不管你做什么生意，所有的一切都是为了让客户最终下单买你的东西，或者让他们觉得你的产品和价格物有所值。那个客户是活生生的人，你要让他们最终转化(conversion)，你就得搞清楚他们怎么看你，怎么看他们自己遇到的问题，还有他们对你产品周围这个世界是怎么理解的。
text_es: Todo en tu negocio, no importa qué tipo de empresa tengas, todo se usa para llevar a alguien a ese punto de conversión o para justificar el producto o el precio que estás ofreciendo. Ese cliente es un ser humano al que estás llevando a ese punto de conversión y tu trabajo es entender cómo te percibe a ti, cómo percibe su problema, cómo percibe el mundo que lo rodea, el mundo alrededor de tus productos.
context: Lenny asks Patrick about customer research and his perspective on why companies often fail to do it properly. Patrick gives his "85-year-old curmudgeonly man perspective" on customer research, emphasizing that despite everyone talking about its importance, only one in five companies have proper buyer personas and only one in ten do regular customer research, even though it dramatically improves all business metrics.
vocabulary_highlights: point of conversion, justify the product

speaker: Paul Adams
speaker_expertise: AI/ML Products, User Experience, Product Design
text: This is a meteor coming towards you. This is going to radically transform society. And I think if people don't explore AI properly, it will leave them behind. I'd start with the thing your product does. "What's the core premise behind it? Why do people use it? What problem does it solve for them?" That kind of thing. So, go back to basics. And then ask, "Can AI do that?"
text_ko: 이건 당신 쪽으로 날아오는 운석이에요. 사회를 근본적으로 바꿔 놓을 거예요. 그리고 사람들이 인공지능(AI)을 제대로 들여다보지 않으면 뒤처질 거라고 생각해요. 저는 우선 제품(product)이 하는 일부터 살펴볼 것 같아요. "그 제품의 핵심 전제(core premise)는 뭔가요? 사람들이 왜 쓰죠? 어떤 문제를 해결해 주나요?" 이런 식으로요. 기본으로 돌아가서, 그리고 나서 "인공지능(AI)이 그걸 할 수 있을까요?"라고 물어보세요.
text_zh: 这就像一颗流星朝你砸过来一样。这会彻底改变整个社会。我觉得如果大家不好好研究AI的话，肯定会被甩在后面。我建议先从你们产品本身入手。"它的核心逻辑是什么？用户为什么要用它？它帮他们解决了什么痛点？"就是这些基本问题。所以，回到原点去思考。然后再问自己，"AI能做这件事吗？"
text_es: Esto es como un meteorito que viene hacia ti. Va a transformar la sociedad de manera radical. Y creo que si la gente no explora bien la IA, se va a quedar atrás. Yo empezaría con lo que hace tu producto. "¿Cuál es la idea central? ¿Por qué lo usa la gente? ¿Qué problema les resuelve?" Ese tipo de cosas. O sea, volver a lo básico. Y después preguntarte: "¿Puede la IA hacer eso?"
context: Lenny asks Paul about his broader insights on AI and how it will integrate into product strategy. Paul explains his belief that AI represents a massive technology shift comparable to or bigger than mobile and the internet. He advocates for a methodical approach to evaluating AI's impact on your product: first understand your core value proposition and user problems, then assess whether AI can solve those same problems.
vocabulary_highlights: meteor coming towards you, radically transform, go back to basics

speaker: Paul Adams
speaker_expertise: AI/ML Products, User Experience, Product Design
text: You can get sidetracked by the technology, for sure. And I do. I just mentioned, hey, going out for dinner and taking a photo of my food. You can get sidetracked by the tech and some of it's really cool. I wouldn't start there. I'd start with the thing your product does. What's the core premise behind it? Why do people use it? What problem does it solve for them? That kind of thing.
text_ko: 물론 기술(technology)에 신경이 쓰여 곁길로 새는 경우가 있어요. 저도 그래요 — 아까 말한 것처럼 저녁 먹으러 가서 음식 사진 찍는 것처럼요. 기술이 멋진 건 맞지만 거기서 시작하진 않아요. 저는 제품(product)이 실제로 뭘 하는지부터 시작해요. 그 밑에 있는 핵심 전제(core premise)는 뭔가요? 사람들이 왜 쓰나요? 어떤 문제를 해결해 주나요? 그런 것들이요.
text_zh: 技术确实容易让人分心，我也会这样。就像我刚说的，出去吃饭还要给菜拍照。你很容易被那些酷炫的技术带跑偏，有些确实挺有意思的。但我不会从这里入手。我会从你的产品本身做什么开始。它的核心价值主张(core premise)是什么？用户为什么要用它？它帮他们解决了什么问题？就是这些东西。
text_es: Claro que te puedes distraer con la tecnología, sin duda. Y a mí me pasa. Como te decía, salir a cenar y tomarle foto a la comida. Te puedes ir por las ramas con la tecnología y algunas cosas están padrísimas. Pero yo no empezaría por ahí. Yo empezaría con lo que hace tu producto en realidad. ¿Cuál es la premisa central? ¿Por qué la gente lo usa? ¿Qué problema les resuelve? Ese tipo de cosas.
context: Lenny asks Paul to elaborate on how to think strategically about whether your product is in the path of AI disruption. Paul warns against getting distracted by flashy AI capabilities and instead recommends starting with fundamental product questions. He emphasizes understanding your product's core value proposition before determining how AI might impact it.
vocabulary_highlights: get sidetracked by, core premise

speaker: Paul Adams
speaker_expertise: AI/ML Products, User Experience, Product Design
text: We literally ripped up our strategy almost entirely, and started again, from first principles and said, "Okay, why do people use Intercom?" Intercom is a customer support product. And then, very soon after that, Sam Altman, who's the founder and head of OpenAI, said, "Hey, one of the first industries that's going to be disrupted is customer service." We're like, "Yep."
text_ko: 우리는 전략을 거의 완전히 갈아엎고 처음부터 다시 시작했어요. 기본 원칙(first principles)부터 다시 되짚어 보면서 “사람들이 왜 Intercom을 쓰는 거지?”라고 물었죠. Intercom은 고객 지원(customer support) 제품이에요. 그리고 얼마 지나지 않아 OpenAI의 창업자 겸 대표인 샘 올트먼이 “가장 먼저 영향을 받게 될 산업 중 하나가 고객 서비스(customer service)다”라고 했어요. 우리는 “그렇죠”라고 했어요.
text_zh: 我们基本上把原来的战略全部推倒重来，从最基本的问题开始思考："用户为什么要用Intercom？"Intercom本质上就是个客服产品。然后没过多久，OpenAI的创始人兼负责人Sam Altman就说："客服行业肯定是首批被AI颠覆的行业之一。"我们当时就想："没错，就是这样。"
text_es: Literalmente tiramos nuestra estrategia casi por completo a la basura y empezamos de cero, desde los principios básicos, y dijimos: "A ver, ¿por qué la gente usa Intercom?" Intercom es un producto de atención al cliente. Y luego, muy poco después, Sam Altman, que es el fundador y director de OpenAI, dijo: "Oye, una de las primeras industrias que va a ser revolucionada es el servicio al cliente." Y nosotros: "Exacto."
context: Lenny asks for an example of how AI can fully replace existing product functionality. Paul describes how Intercom completely changed their strategy after ChatGPT launched on November 29th. When OpenAI's Sam Altman identified customer service as one of the first industries AI would disrupt, Intercom realized they needed to pivot their entire approach and build AI-first solutions.
vocabulary_highlights: ripped up our strategy, from first principles

speaker: Paul Adams
speaker_expertise: AI/ML Products, User Experience, Product Design
text: The advice I have for people, and the advice I have for myself, I'm in that too, I wake up every day to too many emails, and Slack chats, and people knocking on my door, and my desk, and all things. So, this is a challenge for me too. You just have to take the time. There's just no other way for me. And that to me doesn't mean... It's about priorities.
text_ko: 사람들에게 해주는 조언이자 제 자신에게도 하는 말인데요, 저도 그래요. 매일 너무 많은 이메일과 슬랙 메시지, 사람들이 문을 두드리거나 제 책상으로 불쑥 찾아오는 등으로 하루가 시작돼요. 저한테도 큰 도전이에요. 그래서 시간을 따로 내야 해요. 저한텐 다른 방법이 없더라고요. 그리고 그게 의미하는 건… 결국 우선순위의 문제예요.
text_zh: 我给别人的建议，也是给自己的建议，我也是这样的，每天一醒来就是一堆邮件，Slack消息，还有人敲门找我，桌子上也是乱七八糟的，什么都有。所以我也面临这个挑战。你就得挤时间出来，对我来说没别的办法。这不是说... 关键还是看你怎么排优先级。
text_es: El consejo que les doy a otros, y que me doy a mí mismo porque yo también estoy en la misma, es que me levanto cada día con demasiados emails, chats de Slack, gente tocando mi puerta, cosas en mi escritorio, de todo. O sea, para mí también es un reto. Simplemente tienes que darte el tiempo. Para mí no hay de otra. Y eso no significa... Se trata de prioridades.
context: Lenny asks what advice Paul would give to people who want to go deeper into AI but don't have time due to their existing workload. Paul acknowledges he faces the same challenge with emails and meetings, but emphasizes that learning about AI must become a priority. He stresses that staying current with AI isn't optional - it requires dedicated time and prioritization.
vocabulary_highlights: knocking on my door

speaker: Paul Adams
speaker_expertise: AI/ML Products, User Experience, Product Design
text: I think customer support is definitely... Like I said, number one, customer support. So you're like, "Okay, I guess we should adapt." Adapt or die is our mantra. Adapt or die. I think that there are other industries where they're on the same journey, it's just not as obvious.
text_ko: 저는 고객 지원이 확실히... 아까 말했듯이, 가장 중요한 건 고객 지원이에요. 그래서 사람들이 “그럼 우리도 적응해야겠다”라고 생각하죠. '적응하라 아니면 도태된다(Adapt or die)'가 저희 신조예요. 다른 업종들도 같은 길을 가고 있다고 생각하는데, 그게 그렇게 뚜렷하게 보이진 않을 뿐이에요.
text_zh: 我觉得客户服务绝对是...就像我刚说的，排第一位的就是客户服务。所以你就会想，"好吧，看来我们得适应变化了。"适应或淘汰(adapt or die)就是我们的座右铭。要么适应，要么被淘汰。我觉得其他行业其实也在走同样的路，只是没有那么明显而已。
text_es: Creo que el soporte al cliente es definitivamente... Como te dije, número uno, soporte al cliente. Entonces piensas, "Bueno, supongo que tenemos que adaptarnos." Adaptarse o morir es nuestro lema. Adaptarse o morir. Creo que hay otras industrias que están en el mismo camino, simplemente no es tan obvio.
context: Lenny asks what helps people gain conviction about AI's importance, noting that customer support seems like a clear opportunity for AI integration. Paul confirms that customer support was identified as the top industry for AI disruption, making their decision clearer. He introduces Intercom's core philosophy of "adapt or die" while acknowledging that other industries face similar AI transformation challenges, though the path may be less obvious.
vocabulary_highlights: adapt or die

speaker: Paul Adams
speaker_expertise: AI/ML Products, User Experience, Product Design
text: Number one thing I would say is keep it simple. Keep it simple. It's so tempting to... With us, for example, a lot of SaaS products have add-ons, where you're like, "Hey, we built X and that's 10 bucks." Or 100,000, depends on what product you're selling. "We built X and that's the price of X. Hey, we've just built Y. Y is awesome and it's a new thing you can do, and it unlocks all these new capabilities."
text_ko: 제일 먼저 드리고 싶은 말은 단순하게 하라는 거예요. 정말 단순하게 유지하세요. 복잡하게 확장하고 싶어지는 유혹이 크거든요. 예를 들어 우리 같은 경우 많은 SaaS 제품(SaaS products)은 애드온(add-ons)이 있어서 “우리가 X를 만들었고 그게 X의 가격이에요—10달러일 수도 있고 100,000일 수도 있어요(판매하는 제품에 따라 달라요).” 그런 다음에 “방금 Y를 만들었어요. Y는 멋지고 새로운 기능이라서 이걸로 여러 새로운 가능성이 열려요”라고 계속 추가하는 식이에요.
text_zh: 我觉得最重要的一点就是保持简单。一定要保持简单。真的特别容易陷入这样的陷阱...比如说我们这种情况，很多SaaS产品都有附加功能，你会说："嘿，我们开发了X功能，卖10块钱。"或者10万块，这得看你卖的是什么产品了。"我们开发了X功能，X功能就是这个价格。嘿，我们刚开发了Y功能。Y功能超棒的，是个全新的东西，能解锁各种新能力。"
text_es: Lo principal que te diría es que lo mantengas sencillo. Que lo mantengas sencillo. Es súper tentador... Con nosotros, por ejemplo, muchos productos SaaS tienen complementos (add-ons), donde dices, "Oye, creamos X y eso cuesta 10 dólares." O 100,000, depende del producto que vendas. "Creamos X y ese es el precio de X. Oye, acabamos de crear Y. Y está padrísimo y es algo nuevo que puedes hacer, y te abre un montón de nuevas posibilidades."
context: Lenny asks for pricing wisdom based on Paul's experience with Intercom's complex pricing challenges. Paul emphasizes that pricing is deceptively difficult, comparing it to onboarding as one of the hardest design problems. He explains how companies often start simple but gradually add complexity through add-ons and tiers, making customer bills incomprehensible. His key lesson is to resist the temptation to add multiple pricing models.
vocabulary_highlights: keep it simple, deceptively difficult

speaker: Paul Millerd
text: I think the default path is different for everyone and slightly different in every different culture. It's really the story in your head about what you should do. And most of us have some sort of script that we're living out. This is especially powerful when we're in our late teens and early twenties, right? We're trying to execute a script.
text_ko: 사람마다 '기본 경로(default path)'는 다르고, 문화마다도 조금씩 달라요. 본질적으로 그건 '내가 뭘 해야 한다'고 생각하게 만드는 머릿속 이야기예요. 대부분은 저마다 어떤 식의 대본(script)을 가지고 그걸 따라 살고 있어요. 특히 10대 후반에서 20대 초반에는 그 영향력이 더 커서, 그 시기엔 대본을 실행하려고 애쓰죠.
text_zh: 我觉得每个人的默认路径都不一样，在不同文化里也会有差别。其实就是你脑子里那个关于"我应该怎么做"的故事。我们大多数人都在按照某种剧本生活。这在十八九岁到二十出头的时候特别明显，对吧？我们就是在努力按剧本演下去。
text_es: Creo que el camino que seguimos por defecto es diferente para cada persona y varía un poco según la cultura. En realidad es esa historia que tienes en la cabeza sobre lo que deberías hacer. Y la mayoría de nosotros tenemos como un guión que estamos siguiendo. Esto se nota especialmente cuando tienes entre 17-18 y 22-23 años, ¿no? Estás tratando de cumplir con ese guión.
context: Lenny asks Paul to define what he calls the 'default path' - a central concept from Paul's book 'The Pathless Path.' Paul explains that the default path is the conventional life script people follow without conscious choice, typically including going to college, getting a good job, making a good salary, buying a house, getting married, and having a family. He emphasizes that this unconscious script is particularly influential during late teens and early twenties when people are trying to execute what they think they 'should' do rather than what they actually want to do.
vocabulary_highlights: execute a script, sort of script, story in your head

speaker: Paul Millerd
text: A lot of times when people quit their jobs, they forget to fire the manager in their head. They don't realize they can take the afternoon off to spend it with their kids. They've created this implicit contract that Monday through Friday, eight to 10 hours a week you have to work. And that may work for people, but are you actually opting into that, or are you just sort of accepting the default?
text_ko: 사람들이 회사를 그만둘 때면 머릿속에 있는 ‘상사’를 해고하는 걸 잊는 경우가 많아요. 오후에 아이들과 시간을 보내기 위해 오후를 쉬어도 된다는 걸 깨닫지 못하죠. 월요일부터 금요일까지 하루 8~10시간은 일해야 한다는 암묵적 계약(implicit contract)을 스스로 만들어놓은 건데, 그 방식이 누군가에게는 잘 맞을 수 있어요. 그런데 그걸 진짜로 스스로 선택한 건가요, 아니면 그냥 기본값(default)을 수용한 건가요?
text_zh: 很多人辞职创业后，脑子里还是摆脱不了以前那个老板的影子。他们想不到其实可以下午请假去陪孩子玩。在他们心里还是默认周一到周五必须得工作8到10个小时，好像签了什么隐形合同似的。这种模式对有些人来说可能没问题，但你得问问自己：这真的是你主动选择的，还是你就这么稀里糊涂地接受了这个默认设置？
text_es: Muchas veces cuando la gente deja su trabajo, se les olvida despedir al jefe que tienen en la cabeza. No se dan cuenta de que pueden tomarse la tarde libre para estar con sus hijos. Han creado este contrato implícito de que de lunes a viernes tienes que trabajar de ocho a diez horas al día. Y eso puede funcionar para algunas personas, pero ¿realmente estás eligiendo eso conscientemente, o simplemente estás aceptando lo que viene por defecto?
context: Lenny asks about signs that people are still on the default path even when they think they're not. Paul responds by explaining that even when people leave traditional jobs, they often carry the same mental constraints and work patterns with them. He emphasizes the difference between consciously choosing your path versus unconsciously accepting default assumptions about how work should be structured, using the metaphor of 'firing the manager in your head' to describe breaking free from internalized workplace expectations.
vocabulary_highlights: fire the manager in their head, implicit contract, opting into
topics: Career Development, Work-Life Balance, Decision Making

speaker: Paul Millerd
text: My hot take is that we're all on a pathless path. You were at Airbnb. Airbnb, every two years were there was a different company. Right? And so we're constantly needing to reinvent and reevaluate. And I think thinking of our lives as this smooth trajectory up this corporate ascent sort of limits the possibilities of our own life.
text_ko: 제 핫테이크(hot take)는 우리 모두가 '길 없는 길'을 걷고 있다는 거예요. 에어비앤비에 계실 때도 2년마다 완전히 다른 회사에 있는 것 같았잖아요. 그래서 우리는 계속해서 스스로를 재창조하고 재평가해야 해요. 삶을 회사에서 쭉 승진해 올라가는 매끈한 궤적처럼만 생각하면 오히려 우리 삶의 가능성을 제한한다고 생각해요.
text_zh: 我的观点是，咱们其实都在走一条没有路的路。你之前在Airbnb工作，Airbnb每两年就像换了个公司似的，对吧？所以我们得不断地重新定位、重新思考。我觉得如果把人生想象成在公司里一路平稳往上爬的轨迹，这样反而限制了我们人生的各种可能性。
text_es: Mi opinión sincera es que todos estamos en un camino sin rumbo fijo. Estuviste en Airbnb. Airbnb, cada dos años era prácticamente una empresa diferente, ¿no? Y entonces constantemente necesitamos reinventarnos y reevaluar todo. Y creo que pensar en nuestras vidas como esta trayectoria lisa hacia arriba en el ascenso corporativo como que limita las posibilidades de nuestra propia vida.
context: Paul is explaining to Lenny how even traditional corporate careers are actually more uncertain and constantly changing than people realize. He uses Airbnb as an example of how companies evolve so rapidly that employees must constantly adapt and reinvent themselves. Paul argues that the illusion of a 'smooth trajectory up this corporate ascent' actually limits people's thinking about what's possible in their careers, since the reality is that everyone is already navigating uncertainty and change.
vocabulary_highlights: hot take, smooth trajectory, corporate ascent

speaker: Paul Millerd
text: I really shied away from trying to define it super clearly. I think I have this passage at the beginning of the book that it's like the pathless path is basically a shift away from the default. It's a shift away from not knowing what you're doing as a problem to be solved toward an embrace of uncomfort, discomfort, and uncertainty.
text_ko: 저는 그걸 아주 분명하게 정의하려고 하진 않았어요. 책 초반에 이런 구절을 썼는데, 길 없는 길(pathless path)은 기본값에서 벗어나는 변화예요. 다시 말하면, '무엇을 하고 있는지 모르는 상태'를 해결해야 할 문제로 보던 태도에서 벗어나, 불편함과 불확실성을 기꺼이 받아들이는 쪽으로 옮겨가는 거예요.
text_zh: 我当时真的很避免把它定义得太清楚。我觉得在书的开头有这么一段话，就是说这个"无路之路"本质上就是要跳出常规思维。不再把"不知道自己在干什么"当成一个需要解决的问题，而是要学会拥抱那些不舒服、不确定的感觉。
text_es: La verdad es que evité a toda costa tratar de definirlo súper claramente. Creo que tengo un pasaje al inicio del libro donde digo que el sendero sin camino es básicamente un cambio de paradigma, alejándose de lo establecido. Es pasar de ver el no saber qué haces como un problema que hay que resolver, a abrazar la incomodidad y la incertidumbre.
context: Lenny asks Paul to explain his core concept of the 'pathless path' in simple terms. Rather than giving a rigid definition, Paul describes it as a fundamental shift in mindset - moving away from viewing uncertainty as something to be eliminated toward embracing discomfort and not knowing what comes next. He explains this as a personal journey from operating from scarcity toward operating from abundance, requiring faith that things might work out even without a clear plan.
vocabulary_highlights: shied away from, embrace of uncomfort

speaker: Paul Millerd
text: The big aha for me was, 'Oh, you can design around liking work.' The hidden assumption I had around work for the first 32, 33 years of my life was work sucks. You have to figure out how to tolerate it. And within that frame, try to do your best to enjoy some of it. But ultimately, it's a trade-off of your time. You have to suffer through it.
text_ko: 제게 큰 아하 순간은 '일을 좋아하는 쪽으로 설계할 수 있구나'였어요. 제 인생 첫 32~33년 동안 무의식적으로 갖고 있던 일에 대한 전제는 '일은 괴롭다'였어요. 그 틀 안에서는 어떻게든 참아내는 법을 찾아야 하고, 그 안에서 일부를 최대한 즐기려고 애쓰는 식이었죠. 결국엔 시간을 대가로 치르는 거래라고 생각했고, 참아내야만 한다고 믿었어요.
text_zh: 我最大的顿悟就是，"哦，原来工作是可以设计得让人喜欢的。" 我人生前三十二三年一直有个隐性的假设，就是工作就是很痛苦的。你得想办法忍受它。在这个框架里，你尽量让自己享受其中的一些部分。但说到底，这就是拿时间做交换。你必须硬撑过去。
text_es: Para mí el momento de revelación fue: "Ah, puedes diseñar tu trabajo para que te guste". La creencia oculta que tenía sobre el trabajo durante los primeros 32, 33 años de mi vida era que el trabajo apesta. Tienes que averiguar cómo aguantarlo. Y dentro de esa mentalidad, hacer lo posible por disfrutar algo de vez en cuando. Pero al final, es un intercambio de tu tiempo. Tienes que sufrirlo.
context: Paul is sharing his personal transformation in how he thinks about work. He explains that after leaving his traditional job and spending time writing and creating, he discovered he could actually enjoy work rather than just endure it. This was a major revelation that challenged his lifelong assumption that work was inherently something to be tolerated rather than enjoyed. He contrasts his old mindset of work as suffering with his new approach of actively designing work around activities he genuinely likes doing.
vocabulary_highlights: big aha, design around liking work, suffer through it

speaker: Paul Millerd
text: Take three hours during a workday. Has to be during a workday. Block off your schedule, sneak out. People can pull this off. Go for a walk without a destination or do something from your childhood that you used to do all the time. Did you use to play basketball? Did you use to paint? Did you use to play an instrument? And just pay attention.
text_ko: 근무일 중 하루에 3시간 정도 확보하세요. 반드시 근무일에 해야 해요. 일정에 그 시간 블록을 잡고 잠깐 자리를 비워도 돼요—사람들 대부분 해낼 수 있어요. 목적지 없이 산책을 하거나, 어릴 때 늘 하던 일을 해보세요. 예전에 농구를 자주 했나요? 그림을 그리곤 했나요? 악기 연주를 자주 했나요? 그리고 그냥 그 순간에 주의를 기울여 보세요.
text_zh: 找个工作日抽出三个小时，一定要是工作日啊。把日程清空，偷偷溜出去。这个大家都能做到的。去随便走走，不用想去哪儿，或者做点小时候经常做的事情。以前爱打篮球吗？爱画画吗？爱弹琴吗？做这些的时候，就静下心来好好感受。
text_es: Tómate tres horas en un día laboral. Tiene que ser en horario de trabajo, ¿eh? Bloquea tu agenda, escápate un rato. La gente lo puede hacer. Sal a caminar sin rumbo fijo o haz algo de cuando eras niño, algo que hacías todo el tiempo. ¿Jugabas básquet? ¿Pintabas? ¿Tocabas algún instrumento? Y simplemente presta atención.
context: Paul is giving practical advice for people who can't take a full sabbatical but want to start exploring alternatives to their current path. He suggests a simple but powerful exercise: taking a few hours during a workday to reconnect with yourself and activities that used to bring you joy. The key is paying attention to what emerges from this experience - how you feel about sneaking away from work, what activities energize you, and what this reveals about your relationship with work and your definition of what it means to be productive.
vocabulary_highlights: pull this off, sneak out, pay attention

speaker: Paul Millerd
text: I think getting creative, especially now that remote work is so much more common about these opportunities, to let people become the people they want to be. People leave companies because they don't see a path to be the person they want to be.
text_ko: 저는 이런 기회들에 대해, 특히 원격 근무(remote work)가 훨씬 더 보편화된 지금, 좀 더 창의적으로 접근해서 사람들이 원하는 모습으로 성장할 수 있게 해야 한다고 생각해요. 사람들은 자신이 되고 싶은 사람이 될 길이 보이지 않으면 회사를 떠나요.
text_zh: 我觉得现在远程办公这么普及，我们得更有创意地给员工提供机会，让他们成为自己想成为的人。员工离职往往就是因为看不到成长路径，觉得在公司里实现不了自己的目标。
text_es: Creo que hay que ser creativos, especialmente ahora que el trabajo remoto es mucho más común, para crear estas oportunidades que permitan a la gente convertirse en quien quieren ser. La gente se va de las empresas porque no ven un camino para llegar a ser la persona que quieren ser.
context: Paul is addressing founders who might worry about offering sabbaticals to employees, fearing they'll lose good people. He reframes this concern by explaining that people actually leave companies when they can't see opportunities for personal growth and becoming who they want to be. Paul suggests that creative approaches to work arrangements, especially with remote work becoming more common, can actually help retain talent by giving people space to develop into the person they aspire to become.
vocabulary_highlights: getting creative, become the people they want to be

speaker: Pete Kazanjy
text: The thing that I just like to encourage founders and product managers and what have you is just don't be afraid of sales. There's a lot of people out there who would love to tell you a story that it's magical or like, "Oh, you've got to be a born seller," things like that and it's really not. Those people are just talking their book, if you will, and so just getting good at those behaviors, it's going to benefit you in a myriad of ways.
text_ko: 창업자(founders)나 프로덕트 매니저(product managers)분들께 드리고 싶은 말은, 영업(sales)을 너무 두려워하지 말라는 거예요. 영업이 마법 같다고 하거나 “타고난 판매자여야 해”라고 말하는 사람들이 많은데, 사실 전혀 그렇지 않아요. 그런 사람들은 자기 이익을 위해 그런 얘기를 하는 거고요. 그러니까 그런 행동들을 잘 익혀두면 여러모로 도움이 될 거예요.
text_zh: 我就是想鼓励那些创始人、产品经理什么的，千万别害怕销售这件事。外面有很多人会跟你说什么销售很神秘啦，或者"哎呀，你得天生就会卖东西"之类的话，其实根本不是这么回事。这些人就是在为自己说话罢了，所以你把这些销售技能练好了，对你各方面都有好处。
text_es: Lo que me gusta decirles a los fundadores y product managers y demás es simplemente que no le tengan miedo a las ventas. Hay mucha gente por ahí que te va a querer vender el cuento de que es algo mágico o que "ay, tienes que haber nacido para vender" y toda esa historia, pero la verdad es que no es así. Esa gente simplemente está defendiendo su negocio, ¿sabes? Así que ponerte bueno en esas habilidades te va a beneficiar de mil maneras.
context: Lenny asks Pete for his final pieces of wisdom about sales for founders and product managers. Pete emphasizes that sales isn't a mystical skill that requires natural talent, contrary to what some people claim. He explains that the people who perpetuate the myth that sales is magical are simply promoting their own interests or expertise. Pete argues that learning sales behaviors will benefit professionals in many ways, even beyond direct selling situations.
vocabulary_highlights: talking their book, in a myriad of ways, what have you

speaker: Pete Kazanjy
text: Never mistake your lead gen for your business. I think the good news is that a lot of people took a lot of lumps there and folks have learned that, maybe Slack almost missed that, but then they brought in a bunch of Salesforce folks and other folks.
text_ko: 리드 생성(lead gen)을 당신의 비즈니스 그 자체로 착각하지 마세요. 좋은 소식은 많은 사람들이 그 과정에서 시행착오를 많이 겪으면서 배웠다는 거예요. 아마 슬랙은 그걸 거의 놓칠 뻔했는데, 결국 세일즈포스 출신 등 여러 사람들을 영입해서 바로잡았어요.
text_zh: 千万别把获客渠道当成你的核心业务。我觉得好消息是很多人在这方面都吃过亏，大家也都学到了教训。Slack可能差点在这上面栽跟头，但后来他们找来了一批Salesforce的人和其他行业老手。
text_es: Nunca confundas tu generación de leads (lead gen) con tu negocio real. Lo bueno es que mucha gente se pegó buenos golpes ahí y aprendió la lección. Slack casi la cagó con eso, pero luego trajeron a un montón de gente de Salesforce y otras empresas que sabían del tema.
context: Lenny asks Pete whether founders have to get good at sales, especially those building PLG (product-led growth) companies. Pete explains why many PLG companies eventually need to add sales teams to scale beyond their initial self-serve motion. He uses Dropbox as an example of a company that may have delayed building sales capabilities too long, and contrasts it with Slack which successfully added enterprise sales.
vocabulary_highlights: lead gen, took a lot of lumps

speaker: Pete Kazanjy
text: The way to think about what sellers are is they're the microeconomic agents in the market that bring supply to demand rather than waiting for demand to find supply. They have supply in their back pocket and they run around trying to find people who ought to have the demand, maybe they have the demand right now, maybe they don't realize that they have the demand, and then they elucidate to them why they ought to have the demand.
text_ko: 판매자를 이해하는 한 가지 방식은, 그들이 시장에서 수요가 공급을 찾아오길 기다리지 않고 공급을 수요 쪽으로 가져다주는 미시경제적 행위자들(microeconomic agents)이라고 보는 거예요. 판매자들은 공급을 항상 가지고 다니면서, 지금 당장 수요를 가지고 있거나 본인은 모를 수도 있는 사람들을 찾아다니고, 왜 그들이 그 수요를 가져야 하는지(또는 그 제품·서비스가 왜 필요한지)를 설명해줘요.
text_zh: 销售人员其实就是市场里的微观经济主体(microeconomic agents)，他们的作用是主动把供应推向需求，而不是坐等需求自己找上门。他们手里握着货源，到处跑着找那些应该有需求的人——有些人现在就有需求，有些人还没意识到自己有需求，然后销售就去给他们分析为什么他们应该有这个需求。
text_es: La forma de entender a los vendedores es que son los agentes microeconómicos del mercado que llevan la oferta hacia la demanda, en lugar de esperar a que la demanda encuentre la oferta. Tienen la oferta guardada bajo la manga y salen a buscar gente que debería tener esa demanda - tal vez ya la tienen, tal vez no se dan cuenta de que la tienen - y entonces les explican por qué deberían tenerla.
context: Lenny asks Pete to explain what "modern sales" means versus traditional or old-school sales. Pete reframes the perception of salespeople from the stereotypical "sleazy used car salesman" image to viewing them as economic facilitators. He describes modern sales as a more thoughtful, measurable approach where salespeople actively connect solutions to problems in the market, rather than waiting for customers to discover solutions on their own.
vocabulary_highlights: microeconomic agents, have supply in their back pocket, elucidate

speaker: Pete Kazanjy
text: You really just can't do that, not for the first couple dozen customers, it's just not tenable. You lose that feedback loop, you lose the learnings of whether or not your message fits the market, all that sort of stuff. You're playing a game of telephone with that with a third party seller versus even you just want to keep that in one brain to start, then package it, and then when you have a repeatable while loop, a selling while loop, then package it and hand it to someone else.
text_ko: 그건 정말로 할 수 없어요, 처음 몇십 명의 고객을 위해서는 더더욱 그렇고요. 피드백 루프(feedback loop)를 잃게 되면, 메시지가 시장에 맞는지에 대한 배움도 놓치게 돼요. 그렇게 되면 제3자 판매자와 전화게임을 하는 것과 같고요. 처음에는 그 모든 걸 한 사람의 머릿속에 두고 시작한 다음, 패키징해서 반복 가능한 판매 루프(selling while loop)가 생기면 그때 다른 사람에게 넘기는 게 좋죠.
text_zh: 这样做真的不行，至少前几十个客户不能这么搞，根本站不住脚。你会失去反馈循环(feedback loop)，学不到你的信息是否符合市场需求，这些东西都没了。通过第三方销售就像在玩传话游戏一样，还不如一开始就自己掌控全局，等摸清套路了再打包。等你有了可重复的销售循环(selling while loop)，再包装好交给别人去做。
text_es: Simplemente no puedes hacer eso, no con los primeros veinte o treinta clientes, no es viable. Pierdes ese ciclo de retroalimentación (feedback loop), pierdes el aprendizaje de si tu mensaje realmente conecta con el mercado, todas esas cosas. Es como jugar al teléfono roto con un vendedor externo, cuando lo que realmente necesitas es mantener todo eso en una sola cabeza al principio, luego empaquetarlo, y cuando ya tengas un proceso repetible de venta, un bucle de venta (selling while loop) que funcione, ahí sí lo empaquetas y se lo pasas a alguien más.
context: Pete explains why founders must do sales themselves initially rather than outsourcing it to hired salespeople. He describes founder-led sales as the natural sequel to customer development and product building phases. Pete argues that founders are uniquely positioned to become experts at selling their solution because they understand the problem and technology better than any third party could initially learn to.
vocabulary_highlights: not tenable, playing a game of telephone, while loop

speaker: Pete Kazanjy
text: What ends up happening is it's just a skill. You just start doing it, you start doing it, you start doing it, and you just become used to it, you become calloused. You're like, "I'm incorrigible now. You put me in an elevator, I can talk to anyone."
text_ko: 결국엔 그냥 기술이에요. 계속 하다 보면 자연스럽게 되고 익숙해져서 무뎌져요. 이제는 '아, 나 고쳐지지 않겠구나'라고 느낄 정도예요. 엘리베이터에 넣어놔도 누구하고든 얘기할 수 있어요.
text_zh: 结果就是这变成了一种技能。你就是不断地练，不断地练，不断地练，然后就习惯了，就练出厚脸皮了。你会想："我现在是没救了，把我扔电梯里，我跟谁都能聊。"
text_es: Lo que termina pasando es que simplemente se vuelve una habilidad. Empiezas a hacerlo, sigues haciéndolo, sigues haciéndolo, y te acostumbras completamente, te vuelves como inmune. Llegas al punto donde dices: "Ya no hay quien me pare. Me metes en un ascensor y puedo hablar con cualquiera."
context: Lenny asks Pete for his number one tip for getting better at sales. Pete first explains that sales requires a major mindset shift - from working with the same few people daily to meeting multiple new people every day and managing parallel conversations. He describes how this initially uncomfortable behavior becomes natural through repetition, comparing it to building calluses through repeated practice.
vocabulary_highlights: you become calloused, I'm incorrigible now

speaker: Pete Kazanjy
text: As a seller, the way that I like to frame it to people is that you're a consultant that has a particular predilection for a given solution, your solution. Use Atrium as an example. Atrium's minimum ICP is probably SDRs plus AEs in an organization should probably be at 10 all the way up to 300. So, if someone shows up and they're like, "Man, I've got to get really good at sales, I need to buy your software, Pete," and I'm like, "Cool. How many salespeople do you have?" They're like, "I have one." I'll be like, "Man, I'm not going to sell you Atrium."
text_ko: 판매자로서 제가 사람들에게 설명하는 방식은, 여러분이 특정 솔루션에 대한 선호가 있는 컨설턴트라는 거예요. 예를 들어 Atrium을 생각해보면, Atrium의 최소 ICP는 아마도 조직 내에서 SDR과 AE가 10명에서 300명 정도는 되어야 할 것 같아요. 그래서 누군가가 나타나서 "아, 나 정말 세일즈를 잘해야 해, 너희 소프트웨어를 사야겠어, Pete"라고 하면, 제가 "좋아, 세일즈맨이 몇 명이나 있어?"라고 물어볼 거예요. 그 사람이 "한 명 있어요"라고 대답하면, 저는 "아, Atrium은 팔지 않을 거야"라고 말할 거예요.
text_zh: 作为销售，我喜欢这样跟大家说：你其实就是个咨询顾问，只不过你对某个特定的解决方案情有独钟，也就是你自己的产品。拿Atrium举例吧，Atrium的最小理想客户画像(ICP)大概是一个组织里要有SDR加AE总共10到300人这样。所以如果有人过来跟我说："哥们，我得把销售搞好，我要买你的软件，Pete。"我就会问："行啊，那你们有多少销售？"他们说："就一个人。"我就会说："兄弟，那我不会卖Atrium给你的。"
text_es: Como vendedor, la forma en que me gusta planteárselo a la gente es que eres un consultor que tiene una preferencia particular por una solución específica, tu solución. Usa Atrium como ejemplo. El ICP mínimo de Atrium probablemente son SDRs más AEs en una organización que debería estar entre 10 hasta 300. Entonces, si llega alguien y me dice, "Oye, tengo que volverme muy bueno en ventas, necesito comprar tu software, Pete," y yo le digo, "Perfecto. ¿Cuántos vendedores tienes?" Y me responde, "Tengo uno." Le voy a decir, "Mira, no te voy a vender Atrium."
context: Lenny asks Pete about shifting mindset from trying to convince someone to buy something to trying to help them. Pete contrasts old-school sales (like "selling ice to an Eskimo") with modern sales where you act as a consultant with expertise in a particular solution. He gives a practical example of how he would actually refuse to sell Atrium to someone who doesn't fit their ideal customer profile, even if they want to buy.
vocabulary_highlights: particular predilection, minimum ICP

speaker: Peter Deng
speaker_expertise: Product Management, AI/ML Products, Growth Strategy
text: I think education is going to change in a big way. And I think a lot about this because I'm involved in my kid's school quite a bit, and that's something I've done after I left OpenAI. And what's fascinating to me is that watching my son who got to dog food, a bunch of the OpenAI stuff before it was public, I think I can safely say that, that seems okay. And when he was playing with ChatGPT and some of the latest models and he was nine at the time, I can already see his brain rewiring.
text_ko: 교육이 크게 변할 거라고 생각해요. 제가 아이 학교에 많이 참여하고 있어서 이 부분에 대해 많이 고민하게 되는데, OpenAI를 떠난 이후로 계속 그렇게 하고 있어요. 그리고 저에게 흥미로운 점은, 제 아들이 공개되기 전에 OpenAI의 여러 제품을 사용해 본 경험이 있다는 거예요. 그때 그가 ChatGPT 같은 최신 모델을 가지고 놀 때, 아홉 살이었는데, 그의 사고 방식이 이미 바뀌고 있는 걸 느낄 수 있었어요.
text_zh: 我觉得教育肯定会有翻天覆地的变化。我经常想这个问题，因为离开OpenAI之后，我在我儿子学校那边参与得挺多的。最让我觉得神奇的是，看着我儿子体验那些OpenAI还没公开的产品——我觉得可以这么说吧，应该没什么问题。当时他才九岁，在玩ChatGPT和一些最新的模型时，我已经能看出来他的思维方式在发生变化。
text_es: Creo que la educación va a cambiar de manera radical. Y pienso mucho en esto porque estoy bastante involucrado en el colegio de mi hijo, algo que he estado haciendo después de dejar OpenAI. Y lo que me parece fascinante es que al ver a mi hijo, que pudo probar internamente (dog food) un montón de cosas de OpenAI antes de que fueran públicas, creo que puedo decir con seguridad que eso estuvo bien. Y cuando estaba jugando con ChatGPT y algunos de los modelos más recientes - tenía nueve años en ese momento - ya podía ver cómo se le estaba reconfigurando el cerebro.
context: Lenny asks Peter what specific thing will change in a big way with AI that people don't think enough about. Peter explains that education will transform dramatically as young people's minds adapt to AI tools. He shares how his nine-year-old son used ChatGPT and other OpenAI models before they were public, and Peter observed how exposure to AI at an early age was literally changing how his son's brain processed information and approached problems.
vocabulary_highlights: dog food, brain rewiring, I can safely say

speaker: Peter Deng
speaker_expertise: Product Management, AI/ML Products, Growth Strategy
text: Sometimes your product actually doesn't matter. At Uber, I learned this because, really, the price and the ETA at Uber was the product. Looking at it from a holistic perspective, we humans consume the entirety of the product. It's not to say that you shouldn't fix the bug, but it doesn't have as much of an impact as something that is more important to people.
text_ko: 사실 때로는 제품(product) 자체가 크게 중요하지 않을 때가 있어요. 우버에서 일하면서 그걸 배웠어요. 우버에서는 사실 가격과 도착 예정 시간(ETA)이 곧 그 제품이나 마찬가지였거든요. 전체적인 관점에서 보면 사람들은 제품 전체의 경험을 소비해요. 버그(bug)를 안 고치라는 얘기는 아니에요. 다만 사람들에게 더 중요한 것들에 비하면 그런 건 영향력이 크지 않을 때가 많아요.
text_zh: 有时候你的产品本身其实没那么重要。我在优步(Uber)的时候就发现了这一点，因为说白了，优步真正的产品就是价格和预估到达时间(ETA)。从整体角度来看，我们人类消费的是整个产品体验。这不是说你不用修bug，而是这些东西的影响力远不如那些用户真正在意的东西。
text_es: A veces tu producto en realidad no importa tanto. En Uber aprendí esto porque, la verdad, el precio y el tiempo estimado de llegada eran realmente el producto. Si lo ves desde una perspectiva más amplia, nosotros como usuarios consumimos la experiencia completa del producto. No es que no debas arreglar el bug, pero no va a tener tanto impacto como algo que realmente le importa más a la gente.
context: Lenny asks Peter about the most counterintuitive lesson he's learned about building products. Peter shares a hard-learned insight from his time leading the Uber Rider product team - that the digital interface and app features he was optimizing weren't actually the core product. Instead, the real product was the operational elements like pricing and estimated time of arrival, which had much more impact on user satisfaction than any UI improvements.
vocabulary_highlights: holistic perspective, entirety of the product, hard hitting

speaker: Peter Deng
speaker_expertise: Product Management, AI/ML Products, Growth Strategy
text: You have to plan your chess moves out in advance. You have to really think before you act and build systems that were going to let you go sustainably faster. Because the zero to one is you're trying to find that product market fit and then when you get to one to 100, you're trying to make sure you can get to hyperscale as fast as you can.
text_ko: 체스처럼 몇 수 앞을 미리 내다보고 계획해야 해요. 행동하기 전에 충분히 생각하고, 속도를 내되 지속 가능하게 더 빨리 움직일 수 있게 해주는 시스템을 만들어야 해요. 왜냐하면 제로 투 원(zero to one)은 제품-시장 적합도(product-market fit)를 찾는 단계이고, 1에서 100(1 to 100)은 가능한 한 빨리 하이퍼스케일(hyperscale)에 도달할 수 있도록 준비하는 단계이기 때문이에요.
text_zh: 你得提前规划好每一步棋。在行动之前必须深思熟虑，搭建能让你可持续快速发展的体系。因为从零到一(zero to one)阶段，你要找的是产品市场契合度(product market fit)，而到了一到一百(one to 100)阶段，你得确保能以最快速度实现超大规模增长(hyperscale)。
text_es: Tienes que planear tus jugadas de ajedrez con anticipación. Realmente tienes que pensar bien antes de actuar y crear sistemas que te permitan crecer de manera sostenible y más rápido. Porque en la fase de cero a uno estás tratando de encontrar ese ajuste producto-mercado (product market fit), y después cuando llegas a la fase de uno a cien, tienes que asegurarte de poder llegar al hiperescalamiento (hyperscale) lo más rápido posible.
context: Lenny asks Peter about important lessons for building products from idea to billions of users, drawing on Peter's experience scaling products like Facebook Newsfeed, Messenger, Instagram, and ChatGPT. Peter explains that scaling from one to 100 users requires different thinking than finding initial product-market fit - you must build robust systems and infrastructure that will support rapid growth rather than just moving fast and breaking things.
vocabulary_highlights: chess moves out in advance, sustainably faster, hyperscale
topics: Product Management, Strategy & Planning, Leadership & Management

speaker: Peter Deng
speaker_expertise: Product Management, AI/ML Products, Growth Strategy
text: In 6 months, if I'm telling you what to do, I've hired the wrong person. It helps me and the person operate on a different level where the goal is not, did you hit this OKR? The Meta goal becomes, are we calibrating enough? Are we actually getting into a spot where in 6 months you're the one telling me what needs to be done?
text_ko: 6개월 후에 내가 너한테 뭘 해야 한다고 말하고 있다면, 내가 잘못된 사람을 고용한 거야. 그게 나와 너가 다른 차원에서 일하는 데 도움이 돼. 목표가 '이 OKR을 달성했냐?'가 아니라, '우리가 충분히 조율하고 있냐?'로 바뀌는 거지. 6개월 후에는 네가 나한테 뭘 해야 하는지 말해주는 위치에 가는 게 목표야.
text_zh: 六个月后，如果还是我在告诉你该做什么，那说明我招错人了。这样我们俩就能在一个更高的层面上合作，目标不再是你有没有完成这个OKR，而是我们有没有磨合到位？六个月后能不能达到那种状态——变成你来告诉我需要做什么？
text_es: En 6 meses, si yo te tengo que estar diciendo qué hacer, es que contraté a la persona equivocada. Esto nos ayuda tanto a mí como a la persona a operar en otro nivel, donde el objetivo ya no es ¿cumpliste con este OKR? El meta objetivo se convierte en ¿nos estamos calibrando lo suficiente? ¿Realmente estamos llegando al punto donde en 6 meses seas tú quien me diga qué hay que hacer?
context: Lenny asks Peter what he looks for when hiring people. Peter shares his signature hiring philosophy that has helped him build successful teams across Facebook, Instagram, Uber, OpenAI and other companies. Rather than focusing on specific skills, he optimizes for people who can quickly become autonomous and eventually guide him rather than need constant direction, which creates a meta-goal of developing true partnership rather than just task completion.
vocabulary_highlights: meta goal, calibrating enough, operate on a different level

speaker: Peter Deng
speaker_expertise: Product Management, AI/ML Products, Growth Strategy
text: I think there are five different types of product managers. Number one is the consumer PM. This is the person that's half designer, half product person, really obsessed over the details. Another type is the growth PM. These people are half data scientist, half product person, they are wired to think numbers first and they have this air about them that's like the best ones do, which is like, 'I'm really skeptical. Show me the data.'
text_ko: 제품 관리자(product manager)가 다섯 가지 유형이 있다고 생각해요. 첫 번째는 컨슈머 PM(consumer PM)이에요. 이 사람은 반은 디자이너, 반은 제품 담당자(product person) 같은 스타일로 세세한 부분에 진짜 집착해요. 또 다른 유형은 그로스 PM(growth PM)이에요. 이들은 반은 데이터 과학자(data scientist), 반은 제품 담당자(product person)라서 숫자를 가장 먼저 생각하는 사고방식이에요. 그리고 최고의 그들은 ‘저는 정말 회의적이에요. 데이터로 보여주세요.’라는 태도를 풍겨요.
text_zh: 我觉得产品经理(PM)大概分五种类型吧。第一种是消费者产品经理，这种人一半是设计师，一半是产品人，特别抠细节，就是那种细节控。还有一种是增长产品经理，这些人一半是数据科学家，一半是产品人，脑子里第一反应就是数字，而且那些厉害的都有个特点，就是特别较真儿，张口就是"拿数据说话"。
text_es: Creo que hay cinco tipos diferentes de product managers. El primero es el PM de consumidor. Esta persona es mitad diseñador, mitad product person, súper obsesionado con los detalles. Otro tipo es el PM de crecimiento (growth PM). Estas personas son mitad científico de datos, mitad product person, están programados para pensar primero en números y tienen esa actitud que tienen los mejores, que es como 'Soy muy escéptico. Enséñame los datos.'
context: Peter shares a framework he developed at Uber for understanding different product manager archetypes. He explains that rather than viewing PM as a single role, there are five distinct types with different natural motivations and skills. He describes consumer PMs who focus on craft and user experience, and growth PMs who are data-driven and skeptical, noting how these different types create healthy tension when working together on teams.
vocabulary_highlights: wired to think, have this air about them, really skeptical
topics: Product Management, Leadership & Management, Coaching & Development

speaker: Peter Deng
speaker_expertise: Product Management, AI/ML Products, Growth Strategy
text: Say you're going to do the thing, say that you're doing the thing, and then say that you did it. By giving this phrase to Joanne, maybe it was just like, 'Hey, let's just be very intentional about what we build.' That becomes a constant reminder. And it also has this other effect, where if you're saying, 'This is what I'm doing,' and then that's a thing that your manager's like, 'Wait, we don't need to do that anymore,' you can have a conversation about that.
text_ko: 먼저 “이거 할게요”라고 말하고, 하고 있을 땐 “지금 하고 있어요”라고 알리고, 끝나면 “다 했어요”라고 말하세요. 이 말을 조앤에게 건네면서 ‘우리가 만드는 것에 대해 훨씬 더 의도적으로 하자’는 느낌이었을 거예요. 그 말이 계속 상기시켜 주는 역할을 해요. 또 한 가지 효과는, ‘이걸 하고 있다’고 미리 말해 두면 매니저가 ‘잠깐, 그건 이제 안 해도 돼요’라고 할 때 그걸 가지고 대화를 나눌 수 있다는 거예요.
text_zh: 要做什么事就说出来，正在做的时候也要说，做完了还要说一声。我把这话告诉乔安妮，其实就是想说"咱们做什么都得有个明确的目标"。这样能时刻提醒自己。还有个好处，当你说"我现在在做这个"的时候，如果你老板觉得"诶，这事儿不用做了"，你们俩就能马上沟通一下。
text_es: Dile que vas a hacer algo, dile que lo estás haciendo, y después dile que ya lo hiciste. Al darle esta frase a Joanne, tal vez era como decirle, 'Oye, seamos muy claros con lo que vamos a construir.' Se vuelve un recordatorio constante. Y también tiene otro efecto: cuando dices 'Esto es lo que estoy haciendo,' y tu jefe te dice, 'Espera, ya no necesitamos hacer eso,' ahí puedes tener una conversación al respecto.
context: Lenny asks Peter about management advice he gave to Joanne Jang at OpenAI for managing up more effectively. Peter explains this simple three-part communication framework that helps people stay aligned with their managers and teams. The framework forces intentionality in planning, creates opportunities for course correction during execution, and ensures proper communication of completed work and impact.
vocabulary_highlights: very intentional, constant reminder, course correction
topics: Communication Skills, Leadership & Management, Strategy & Planning

speaker: Petra Wille
speaker_expertise: Executive Coaching, Marketing Strategy, Community Building
text: Getting promoted is way harder if you're not good in telling stories and rallying the team behind the shared goal and all these kind of things, and you usually achieve this through good storytelling techniques. And in some teams, I've seen the product person not being really, really good at it, but then the whole team helped creating these stories and stuff like this. So you definitely could compensate to some extent, but I would consider it a bit of a career staller if you don't get to a decent level of storytelling and to a decent level of public speaking.
text_ko: 사람들을 설득해서 같은 목표로 모으는 능력, 그리고 이야기를 잘 만드는 능력이 부족하면 승진이 훨씬 어려워요. 보통은 좋은 스토리텔링 기법(storytelling techniques)을 통해 그런 역량을 기르게 돼요. 어떤 팀에서는 프로덕트 담당자(product person)가 그걸 아주 잘 못해도 팀 전체가 함께 이야기를 만들어 보완해 주는 경우를 봤어요. 그래서 어느 정도는 팀으로 보완이 가능하지만, 스토리텔링과 대중 앞 말하기(public speaking) 수준을 어느 정도로 끌어올리지 못하면 경력이 정체될 수 있다고 생각해요.
text_zh: 如果你不会讲故事，不会把团队拧成一股绳朝着共同目标努力，升职就会特别难。这些能力通常都要靠好的storytelling技巧来实现。我见过一些团队里，产品经理本身这方面不太行，但整个团队会帮着一起打造这些故事什么的。所以在一定程度上确实可以互补，但我觉得如果你的storytelling和公开演讲水平达不到一定程度的话，对职业发展还是会有阻碍的。
text_es: Es mucho más difícil que te asciendan si no sabes contar historias y motivar al equipo hacia un objetivo común y todas esas cosas, y esto normalmente lo logras con buenas técnicas de storytelling. Y en algunos equipos, he visto que la persona de producto no era súper buena en esto, pero entonces todo el equipo ayudaba a crear estas historias y cosas así. Definitivamente puedes compensarlo hasta cierto punto, pero yo lo consideraría como algo que te frena en tu carrera si no llegas a un nivel decente de storytelling y a un nivel decente para hablar en público.
context: Lenny asks Petra about the importance of storytelling and public speaking skills for product managers. Petra explains that while you can do IC-level product management work without strong storytelling abilities, it becomes a significant barrier to career advancement. She notes that getting promoted requires rallying teams around shared goals, which is primarily achieved through effective storytelling techniques.
vocabulary_highlights: rallying the team, career staller, decent level, compensate to some extent
topics: Career Development, Communication Skills, Leadership & Management

speaker: Petra Wille
speaker_expertise: Executive Coaching, Marketing Strategy, Community Building
text: One thing that has made me sense out the most is I see product people on the IC level have to go through some of the struggles on their own, even if our product community has some best practices to it. Because as the line manager has no clue about the product community out there and the craftless product management, they often struggle to point them in the right direction to say, 'Hey, I think that's a problem somebody else already had. So maybe you could watch a talk or read this blog post or there's a book about this particular thing and then go try it.'
text_ko: 제가 가장 크게 느낀 것 중 하나는 IC 레벨(IC level)의 프로덕트 담당자들(product people)이 프로덕트 커뮤니티(product community)에 모범 사례(best practices)가 있더라도 어느 정도는 스스로 어려움을 겪어야 한다는 점이에요. 라인 매니저(line manager)들이 그 커뮤니티나 프로덕트 관리의 전문성 부족(craftless product management)에 대해 잘 모르는 경우가 많아서, "그건 누군가 이미 겪은 문제인 것 같은데 관련 강연(talk)을 보거나 이 블로그 글(blog post)을 읽어보거나 이 주제에 관한 책이 있으니 읽어보고 한번 시도해보세요"처럼 바로 적절한 방향을 가리켜 주기 어렵더라고요.
text_zh: 最让我困惑的一点就是，我发现那些一线的产品经理们经常得自己摸索解决问题，其实咱们产品圈子里已经有不少最佳实践了。问题是他们的直线经理对外面的产品社区和专业的产品管理方法根本不了解，所以没法给他们指对方向，比如说"嘿，我觉得这个问题别人肯定遇到过，你可以去看看某个演讲视频，或者读读相关的博客文章，或者有专门讲这个的书，然后你去试试看。"
text_es: Lo que más me ha llamado la atención es que veo a la gente de producto a nivel individual contributor (IC level) teniendo que lidiar con muchos problemas por su cuenta, aunque nuestra comunidad de producto ya tenga buenas prácticas para esto. El tema es que como el jefe directo no tiene ni idea de lo que pasa en la comunidad de producto ni del product management como disciplina, muchas veces no saben orientarlos bien para decirles: "Oye, creo que este problema ya lo tuvo alguien más. Tal vez podrías ver esta charla o leer este post, o hay un libro sobre este tema específico, y después lo pruebas."
context: Lenny asks what non-product people who lead product teams lack most in terms of understanding product management. Petra explains that managers from other backgrounds often don't understand the product management craft or community, so they can't guide their product people toward existing solutions and resources. This forces individual contributor product managers to learn everything on their own instead of being directed to established best practices and learning materials.
vocabulary_highlights: sense out the most, IC level, line manager, point them in the right direction
topics: Leadership & Management, Coaching & Development, Learning & Growth

speaker: Petra Wille
speaker_expertise: Executive Coaching, Marketing Strategy, Community Building
text: Then step number two is having a clear idea where every PM currently is in their current career, in their situation, life in general, all these kind of things. So put the pin on the map, so to say, and then think about what is your vision for them in the future, so how good could it get? And I usually encourage product leads to think bigger than their current role at the current company because that's the longer term thing. And then even more important is what I call the next bigger challenge.
