text_ko: 두 번째 단계는 각 PM(product manager)이 지금 커리어나 처한 상황, 삶 전반에서 정확히 어디에 있는지 명확히 아는 거예요. 지도에 핀을 찍듯 현재 위치를 표시하고, 그다음 그 사람의 미래 비전—얼마나 더 잘할 수 있을지—을 생각해보세요. 저는 보통 프로덕트 리드(product lead)들에게 현재 회사에서의 역할보다 더 크게, 장기적으로 생각하라고 권해요. 그리고 더 중요한 건 제가 '다음 큰 도전(next bigger challenge)'이라고 부르는 다음 단계예요.
text_zh: 第二步就是要清楚地知道每个PM现在的状态——他们的职业发展到哪儿了，现在是什么情况，生活上怎么样，这些方方面面的事情。就是说要先定个位，然后再想想你对他们未来的设想，就是最好能发展到什么程度？我通常建议产品负责人把眼光放远一点，别只盯着他们现在这个公司的这个岗位，因为要考虑长远发展嘛。然后更重要的是我说的"下一个更大的挑战"。
text_es: Entonces el paso número dos es tener una idea clara de dónde está cada PM en este momento en su carrera, en su situación, en la vida en general, todas esas cosas. O sea, ponerle el alfiler al mapa, por así decirlo, y después pensar cuál es tu visión para ellos en el futuro, ¿qué tan bien podrían llegar a estar? Y yo siempre les digo a los líderes de producto que piensen más allá de su puesto actual en la empresa donde están ahora, porque eso es lo que importa a largo plazo. Y aún más importante es lo que yo llamo el siguiente gran reto.
context: Lenny asks Petra about her five ingredients for coaching product managers effectively. Petra is explaining the second ingredient, which involves assessing where each PM currently stands and creating a vision for their development. She emphasizes that product leaders should think beyond just the current role and company when envisioning their team member's growth potential, and focus on identifying the next meaningful challenge that would help them develop new skills.
vocabulary_highlights: put the pin on the map, think bigger than, next bigger challenge

speaker: Petra Wille
speaker_expertise: Executive Coaching, Marketing Strategy, Community Building
text: First of all, people that's starting, often they are getting a better storytelling journey. Often totally underestimate how many time actually great storytellers are investing in creating the stories and making sure they can share the story in nice ways and formats. So that's maybe the first tip, you have to plan to put in a lot of work to create your story.
text_ko: 무엇보다 시작하는 사람들은 종종 스토리텔링 여정(storytelling journey)이 더 쉽다고 생각하기 쉬워요. 많은 분들이 훌륭한 스토리텔러들이 이야기를 만들고 보기 좋은 형식으로 공유할 수 있게 다듬는 데 실제로 얼마나 많은 시간을 투자하는지 완전히 과소평가하죠. 그래서 첫 번째 팁은 스토리를 만들려면 많은 노력을 들일 예정이라고 계획하라는 거예요.
text_zh: 首先啊，刚开始做storytelling的人，他们往往会低估一个事情，就是那些真正会讲故事的高手，其实在背后下了多少功夫去打磨故事，还有怎么用最好的方式和形式把故事讲出来。所以我第一个建议就是，你得做好心理准备，要花大量的时间和精力去打造你的故事。
text_es: Primero que nada, la gente que está empezando, a menudo está creando mejores narrativas empresariales. Pero casi siempre subestiman cuánto tiempo invierten realmente los grandes narradores en crear sus historias y asegurarse de que pueden contarlas de manera atractiva y en diferentes formatos. Así que ese sería mi primer consejo: tienes que estar preparado para invertir mucho trabajo en crear tu historia.
context: Lenny asks Petra for concrete advice on how product managers can become better storytellers. Petra explains that people beginning their storytelling improvement journey often don't realize how much time and effort great storytellers invest in crafting their stories. She emphasizes that creating compelling stories requires significant preparation and iteration, not just natural talent or quick improvisation.
vocabulary_highlights: totally underestimate, put in a lot of work

speaker: Petra Wille
speaker_expertise: Executive Coaching, Marketing Strategy, Community Building
text: And then the other tip would be really make sure that you're using language that speaks to the heart and the minds of the people because we constantly tend to use too much of our business lingo and it's banner blindness. Some of the words that we're using people totally overhearing them because we're using them so often. And it could be even things like product discovery. So maybe your company is already so fed up with all your product discovery stuff that you should start using different terms.
text_ko: 그리고 다른 팁은 사람들의 마음과 머리에 와닿는 언어를 꼭 쓰라는 거예요. 우리는 자꾸 비즈니스 전문용어만 쓰는 경향이 있는데, 그게 배너 블라인드니스(banner blindness)처럼 돼서 말들이 묻혀버려요. 너무 자주 쓰다 보면 어떤 단어들은 사람들이 아예 못 들은 척 하거든요. 예를 들어 프로덕트 디스커버리(product discovery) 같은 표현도 그럴 수 있어요. 회사에서 그 표현에 이미 모두가 지쳐 있다면, 다른 말로 바꿔 쓰는 게 좋아요.
text_zh: 还有一个建议就是，你一定要用能打动人心的话，因为我们总是喜欢用太多商业术语，结果就像横幅盲区(banner blindness)一样——用得太频繁了，大家都听麻木了，直接就过滤掉了。比如说"产品发现(product discovery)"这种词，可能你们公司的人已经听腻了，那就该换个说法了。
text_es: Y luego el otro consejo sería asegurarte de que realmente estés usando un lenguaje que le llegue tanto al corazón como a la mente de la gente, porque constantemente tendemos a usar demasiada jerga empresarial y eso genera ceguera de banner (banner blindness). Algunas de las palabras que usamos la gente ya ni las escucha porque las repetimos tanto. Y puede ser hasta cosas como descubrimiento de producto (product discovery). Entonces tal vez tu empresa ya esté hasta el gorro de todo tu rollo de product discovery y deberías empezar a usar términos diferentes.
context: Lenny asks for concrete storytelling advice for product managers. Petra explains that effective storytelling requires using natural, emotional language rather than business jargon. She introduces the concept of "banner blindness" - when audiences tune out overused corporate terms. She suggests that even established product management terminology like "product discovery" might need to be replaced with simpler, more relatable language if teams have become desensitized to it.
vocabulary_highlights: speaks to the heart and the minds, banner blindness, totally overhearing, fed up with

speaker: Petra Wille
speaker_expertise: Executive Coaching, Marketing Strategy, Community Building
text: For example, I found that oftentimes there is a bit of a community of practice internally, but they never heard about external product community. So they never heard of your community or to raise this community or mind the product or any of those external communities. And that is shocking to an extent as well because we're all so friendly human beings, happy to share what we learn, and they don't have to go through the same things over and over again.
text_ko: 예를 들어, 내부에는 종종 실무 커뮤니티가 있지만, 외부 제품 커뮤니티에 대해 들어본 적이 없는 경우가 많아요. 그래서 그들은 당신의 커뮤니티나 제품 관련 커뮤니티에 대해 전혀 알지 못해요. 이건 어느 정도 충격적이기도 해요. 우리는 모두 친절한 사람들인데, 배운 것을 기꺼이 나누고 싶어 하잖아요. 같은 일을 반복해서 겪지 않아도 되니까요.
text_zh: 比如说，我发现很多公司内部都有实践社区(community of practice)，但他们压根没听说过外部的产品社区。他们不知道你们的社区，也不知道怎么去建立这种社区，或者关注产品，或者其他那些外部社区。这真的挺让人意外的，因为大家都是很友善的人，都愿意分享自己学到的东西，这样别人就不用重复踩同样的坑了。
text_es: Por ejemplo, me di cuenta de que muchas veces sí hay como una comunidad de práctica interna, pero nunca han escuchado sobre las comunidades externas de producto. O sea, nunca han oído hablar de tu comunidad o de cómo crear esta comunidad o cuidar el producto, ni de ninguna de esas comunidades externas. Y eso también me sorprende bastante porque todos somos seres humanos súper amigables, dispuestos a compartir lo que aprendemos, y no tienen por qué pasar por las mismas cosas una y otra vez.
context: Lenny asks about Petra's research into product management communities and their value. Petra explains her survey findings about how many product managers are unaware of external communities like Lenny's community, Teresa Torres' community, or Mind the Product. She finds this surprising given how willing people in the product community are to share knowledge and help others avoid repeating the same mistakes and challenges.
vocabulary_highlights: community of practice, shocking to an extent, go through the same things

speaker: Phyl Terry
speaker_expertise: User Experience, Career Development, Leadership Development
text: While it's hard to figure out your candidate market fit, it's also a relief to know it's not about you. So what I ask people to do is I ask them to think about what they want and what they don't want. Now, you might not think that that's a radical step, Lenny, but most people don't do that. When they get laid off, they spray and pray.
text_ko: 후보자 시장 적합성(candidate market fit)을 파악하는 건 어렵지만, 그게 당신 개인 문제만은 아니라는 걸 알면 오히려 한숨 돌릴 수 있어요. 그래서 제가 사람들에게 부탁하는 건, 자신이 원하는 것과 원하지 않는 것을 먼저 생각해 보라는 거예요. Lenny, 이게 대단한 발상 같지 않을 수도 있지만, 사실 대부분의 사람들은 그렇게 하지 않아요. 해고당하면 대부분 무작정 여기저기 지원하고 운에 맡기거든요 (spray and pray).
text_zh: 虽然搞清楚自己和目标市场的匹配度(candidate market fit)挺难的，但换个角度想，这事儿跟你个人能力没关系，这样想会轻松不少。所以我会让大家做的就是，先想清楚自己要什么，不要什么。你可能觉得这没什么，Lenny，但大多数人其实都不会这么做。他们一被裁员，就开始海投简历碰运气。
text_es: Aunque es difícil encontrar el ajuste perfecto con el mercado laboral (candidate market fit), también es un alivio saber que no es algo personal. Entonces lo que les pido a las personas es que piensen en qué es lo que sí quieren y qué es lo que no quieren. Puede que no te parezca algo revolucionario, Lenny, pero la mayoría de la gente no hace esto. Cuando los despiden, salen disparando currículos a lo loco esperando que algo pegue.
context: Lenny asks how Phyl realized this candidate market fit method is powerful versus traditional job searching approaches. Phyl explains that candidate market fit is about understanding where you fit in the job marketplace based on supply and demand, not personal worth. She emphasizes that the first step is defining what you want and don't want in a role, which most people skip when they get laid off and instead immediately start applying everywhere without strategy.
vocabulary_highlights: spray and pray, radical step

speaker: Phyl Terry
speaker_expertise: User Experience, Career Development, Leadership Development
text: When you're looking for a job, you need a spear and not a net. What happens when we're building a product? Same thing, right? We want this product to be for everyone, but we've learned with product market fit that doesn't work. We need a narrow, clear focus.
text_ko: 구직할 땐 그물보다 창이 필요해요. 제품을 만들 때도 마찬가지예요. 이 제품을 모두를 위한 것으로 만들고 싶지만, 제품-시장 적합성(product-market fit)을 겪어 보니 그 방식은 통하지 않더라고요. 좁고 명확한 초점이 필요해요.
text_zh: 找工作的时候，你得用长矛，不能撒大网。做产品其实也是一个道理，对吧？我们总想让产品适合所有人，但从产品市场匹配度(product market fit)的经验来看，这样是行不通的。我们需要专注，目标要明确，范围要收窄。
text_es: Cuando estás buscando trabajo, necesitas una lanza, no una red. ¿Qué pasa cuando desarrollamos un producto? Lo mismo, ¿verdad? Queremos que este producto sea para todo el mundo, pero ya hemos aprendido que con el product market fit eso no funciona. Necesitamos un enfoque muy específico y claro.
context: Phyl is explaining her philosophy about candidate market fit, drawing parallels between job searching and product development. She argues that just as products need focused target markets rather than trying to appeal to everyone, job seekers need specific, narrow focus in their search rather than casting a wide net. This approach helps people be more memorable and creates better opportunities.
vocabulary_highlights: spear and not a net
topics: Product Management, Career Development, Strategy & Planning

speaker: Phyl Terry
speaker_expertise: User Experience, Career Development, Leadership Development
text: There's no I in team. Well, there is an I in village, and the I in village is that when you start to interview and negotiate, you've got to be in charge. I want you to play to win, not not to lose.
text_ko: 팀에는 '나'가 없다고들 하죠. 그런데 'village'에는 'I'가 있어요. 여기서 말하는 'I'는 면접이나 협상에 들어갈 때 주도권을 잡아야 한다는 뜻이에요. 저는 여러분이 지지 않으려고만 하지 말고, 이기기 위해 적극적으로 나서길 바라요.
text_zh: 团队里没有"我"字。不过呢，在打造团队这件事上，"我"还是很重要的，因为当你去面试和谈判的时候，你必须得主导局面。我希望你们是奔着赢去的，而不是光想着别输。
text_es: No hay "yo" en equipo. Bueno, pero sí hay un "yo" en liderazgo, y ese "yo" significa que cuando empiezas a entrevistar y negociar, tienes que tomar las riendas. Quiero que juegues para ganar, no para no perder.
context: Phyl is discussing her philosophy about taking control during the job search process. While emphasizing the importance of community support through job search councils, she explains that individuals must still take personal responsibility and be proactive during interviews and negotiations. The concept of 'playing to win, not not to lose' means being confident and strategic rather than defensive or passive.
vocabulary_highlights: play to win, not not to lose

speaker: Phyl Terry
speaker_expertise: User Experience, Career Development, Leadership Development
text: I want you to create what I call a job mission with OKRs. Most job descriptions, they suck, Lenny. The company doesn't know what the eff they're doing. They don't know exactly what they're looking for. But I'm not telling you to say that to them, just to be clear. I'm telling you, 'I want you to create your own job mission with OKRs.'
text_ko: 대부분의 직무 설명서는 엉망이에요, Lenny. 회사가 도대체 뭘 하는지 모르겠고, 어떤 사람을 정확히 원하는지도 모르는 경우가 많아요. 근데 그걸 그들에게 그대로 말하라는 건 아니고, 그냥 분명히 해두는 거예요. 제 말은, '자신만의 직무 미션(job mission)을 OKR(OKRs)로 만들어 달라'는 거예요.
text_zh: 我希望你自己制定一个工作使命，配上OKRs（目标和关键结果）。说实话，大部分职位描述都写得一塌糊涂，Lenny。公司自己都搞不清楚在干什么，根本不知道到底要找什么样的人。当然了，我不是让你当面这么跟他们说，你懂的。我的意思是，你要主动出击，给自己定一个清晰的工作使命和OKRs。
text_es: Quiero que te armes lo que yo llamo una misión de trabajo con OKRs. La mayoría de las descripciones de puesto son un desastre, Lenny. La empresa no tiene ni idea de lo que está haciendo. No saben exactamente lo que buscan. Pero ojo, no te estoy diciendo que les digas eso, para que quede claro. Lo que te digo es: 'Quiero que te crees tu propia misión de trabajo con OKRs.'
context: Phyl is explaining one of her key interview tactics where job candidates create their own version of the job description with specific objectives and key results (OKRs). She argues that most companies have poorly written job descriptions and don't clearly know what they want, so candidates should privately develop their own understanding of what the role should accomplish, which can then be shared with hiring managers to demonstrate initiative and strategic thinking.
vocabulary_highlights: what the eff they're doing

speaker: Phyl Terry
speaker_expertise: User Experience, Career Development, Leadership Development
text: If someone did this, it would blow my mind. I would hire them on the spot.
text_ko: 누군가 이런 걸 해낸다면 정말 깜짝 놀랄 거예요. 그 자리에서 바로 고용할 거예요.
text_zh: 要是有人能做到这个，我真的会被震撼到。我会当场就录用他。
text_es: Si alguien hiciera esto, me dejaría impresionado. Lo contrataría inmediatamente.
context: Phyl is quoting a senior Amazon executive who has hired over 2,000 product leaders, describing his reaction to candidates who present a job mission with OKRs during interviews. This quote emphasizes how rare and impressive this tactic is - most candidates never do this level of preparation, so those who do immediately stand out and demonstrate their strategic thinking and commitment to success in the role.
vocabulary_highlights: blow my mind, on the spot

speaker: Phyl Terry
speaker_expertise: User Experience, Career Development, Leadership Development
text: Asking for help is not a sign of weakness, it's a sign of confidence. It both requires confidence and strengthens it, Lenny. Two, it's not a taking activity, it's a giving activity. If you do it well, you're actually being giving to the people you ask.
text_ko: 도움을 요청하는 건 약함의 표시가 아니라 자신감의 표현이에요. 도와달라고 하려면 자신감이 필요하고, 또 그런 과정을 통해 자신감이 더 강해져요, Lenny. 두 번째로, 도움을 청하는 건 받기만 하는 행위가 아니라 주는 행위예요. 잘하면 도움을 요청받는 사람들에게 오히려 베푸는 셈이에요.
text_zh: 寻求帮助不是软弱的表现，而是自信的体现。这既需要自信，也能增强自信，Lenny。第二点，这不是索取，而是给予。如果你做得好，其实是在给那些你求助的人机会。
text_es: Pedir ayuda no es señal de debilidad, es señal de que tienes confianza en ti mismo. Te exige tener seguridad y a la vez te la refuerza, Lenny. Segundo, no es algo donde solo recibes, es algo donde también das. Si lo haces bien, en realidad les estás dando algo valioso a las personas a las que les pides ayuda.
context: Lenny asks Phyl about her expertise in teaching people how to ask for help, noting it was a common theme when he asked people what she's amazing at. Phyl is explaining her counterintuitive philosophy about asking for help, arguing against common misconceptions. She outlines four key principles: asking for help shows confidence rather than weakness, it's actually a generous act toward the person being asked, and when done properly with preparation and vulnerability, people feel honored to be asked for their expertise.
vocabulary_highlights: counterintuitive, being giving to

speaker: Raaz Herzberg
speaker_expertise: Product Management, B2B SaaS, Marketing Strategy
text: At the time, we didn't really have a solid product yet. We would have 10 to 15 meetings every day with potential customers. I was hired as the first product manager. I sat in on those calls. I still did not exactly understand what we were going to build, which was confusing, because I was a product manager, so I was supposed to start building it, and so, at some point, it was like, "I have to ask, what exactly are we doing here?" And that ended up pivoting us around to cloud security.
text_ko: 그때는 아직 제대로 된 제품이 없었어요. 매일 잠재 고객들과 미팅을 10~15개씩 했죠. 저는 첫 번째 제품 매니저(product manager)로 채용돼서 그 통화들에 모두 참여했어요. 그런데도 우리가 정확히 뭘 만들 건지 잘 이해가 안 됐어요. 제품 매니저였으니 당연히 그걸 시작해야 했기 때문에 더 혼란스러웠죠. 결국에는 "우리가 정확히 뭘 하는 거죠?"라고 물어봤고, 그 질문이 결국 우리를 클라우드 보안(cloud security) 쪽으로 피벗(pivot)하게 만들었어요.
text_zh: 当时我们其实还没有什么像样的产品。我们每天要跟潜在客户开10到15个会。我是被招进来做第一个产品经理(product manager)的。那些电话会议我都参加了。但说实话，我还是搞不清楚我们到底要做什么产品，这就很尴尬了，因为我是产品经理啊，按理说应该由我来负责产品开发的。所以到了某个时候，我实在忍不住了，就问："咱们到底在搞什么啊？"结果就是这么一问，我们就转向了云安全(cloud security)这个方向。
text_es: En ese momento, la verdad es que no teníamos un producto sólido todavía. Nos metíamos en 10 o 15 reuniones diarias con clientes potenciales. Me contrataron como el primer gerente de producto. Me quedaba en esas llamadas escuchando. Seguía sin entender exactamente qué íbamos a desarrollar, lo cual era confuso, porque yo era el gerente de producto, se supone que tenía que empezar a construirlo, y entonces, en algún momento fue como, "Tengo que preguntar, ¿qué estamos haciendo aquí exactamente?" Y eso terminó haciéndonos dar la vuelta hacia la seguridad en la nube (cloud security).
context: Lenny asks Raaz about the early days at Wiz when the company was struggling to find the right product direction. Raaz explains how she joined as the first product manager during a confusing period where the team was having many customer meetings but nobody really understood what they were building. After weeks of customer calls where she couldn't grasp what product they were supposed to develop, she finally asked the direct question that led to their successful pivot to cloud security.
vocabulary_highlights: ended up pivoting us around
topics: Starting a Company, Product Management, Decision Making

speaker: Raaz Herzberg
speaker_expertise: Product Management, B2B SaaS, Marketing Strategy
text: We really felt the type of questions change, right? Silly. The call sounded like, again, "How are you pricing this, or when can we start doing a POV?" I think naturally, as human beings, you have a bias to look for affirmation, versus a bias for what you don't want to hear.
text_ko: 질문 유형이 확실히 바뀐 걸 느꼈죠? 우습게도 통화 내용이 다시 "이거 가격은 어떻게 되나요? 언제부터 POV(Proof of Value)을 시작할 수 있나요?" 이런 식이었어요. 사람은 본능적으로 긍정 확인을 받고 싶어하는 쪽으로 치우치고, 듣기 싫은 얘기를 먼저 들으려 하진 않아요.
text_zh: 我们真的感觉到客户问的问题变了，对吧？特别明显。电话里听起来就是，又开始问"你们怎么定价的，什么时候可以开始做概念验证(POV)？"我觉得这很自然，人嘛，总是倾向于找认同感，而不愿意听那些不中听的话。
text_es: Realmente notamos que el tipo de preguntas cambió, ¿verdad? Una tontería. Las llamadas sonaban como, otra vez, "¿Cómo están manejando los precios de esto, o cuándo podemos empezar a hacer un POV?" Creo que naturalmente, como seres humanos, tienes una tendencia a buscar confirmación, en lugar de una tendencia hacia lo que no quieres escuchar.
context: Lenny asks about the signals that showed when Wiz finally found product-market fit after their pivot to cloud security. Raaz describes how customer conversations completely changed from polite interest to urgent practical questions. She explains that customers stopped saying generic positive things and started asking specific questions about pricing and proof-of-value (POV) trials, indicating real purchasing intent rather than just politeness.
vocabulary_highlights: bias to look for affirmation, bias for what you don't want to hear

speaker: Raaz Herzberg
speaker_expertise: Product Management, B2B SaaS, Marketing Strategy
text: I had a ton to learn about marketing, with what I knew really well, with the problem we solved, and I really knew our audience. I myself, I come from security, I come from cloud security, I read all of the right Twitters, and I follow all of the right people on Twitter, and I read all of the right blogs. I know it's funny, I know what matters, I know it's interesting right now, generally because, this is my space.
text_ko: 마케팅(marketing)에 대해 배울 게 한참 있었어요. 제가 이미 잘 알고 있던 것들, 우리가 해결한 문제와 관련해서요. 대신 우리 청중(audience)에 대해서는 정말 잘 알고 있었어요. 저는 보안(security), 특히 클라우드 보안(cloud security) 출신이라서요. 트위터(Twitter)에서 중요한 사람들은 다 팔로우하고 관련 트윗도 챙겨 보고, 관련 블로그(blogs)들도 다 읽었어요. 웃긴 얘기지만 뭘 중요하게 생각해야 하는지, 지금 무엇이 흥미로운지는 잘 알고 있어요 — 대체로 이게 제 영역이거든요.
text_zh: 在营销这块我要学的东西太多了，但我对我们解决的问题和我们的用户群体非常了解。我本身就是做安全出身的，做云安全的，该关注的Twitter账号我都关注了，该follow的人我都follow了，该看的博客我都看。我知道什么有意思，知道什么重要，知道现在什么最火，因为这就是我的地盘嘛。
text_es: Tenía muchísimo que aprender sobre marketing, pero lo que sí conocía muy bien era el problema que resolvíamos y realmente conocía a nuestra audiencia. Yo vengo del mundo de la seguridad, de seguridad en la nube, sigo todas las cuentas correctas en Twitter, leo a toda la gente indicada en Twitter, y leo todos los blogs que importan. Sé qué es gracioso, sé qué importa, sé qué está interesante ahorita, básicamente porque este es mi terreno.
context: Lenny asks why Raaz thinks she was successful in marketing despite being new to the field. Raaz explains her unconventional approach to becoming CMO at Wiz. While she had no traditional marketing experience, she had deep domain expertise in cloud security and understood the target audience intimately because she lived in that space as a former customer herself.
vocabulary_highlights: had a ton to learn, this is my space

speaker: Raaz Herzberg
speaker_expertise: Product Management, B2B SaaS, Marketing Strategy
text: Marketing is quite the opposite, in my opinion. There's no cost to anything, no maintenance to anything, no technical depth, no anything. If tomorrow I post a video on Wiz's LinkedIn page, and I think that video is super funny, and nobody likes that video, nothing happened. Tomorrow, I'll post a different video, no maintenance, bye-bye, forgot it ever happened.
text_ko: 제 생각엔 마케팅은 완전히 반대예요. 비용도 별로 들지 않고, 유지보수(maintenance)도 필요 없고, 기술적 깊이(technical depth)도 없고, 딱히 아무 것도 아니에요. 예를 들어 내일 제가 Wiz의 LinkedIn 페이지에 영상을 올리고 제가 그걸 엄청 웃기다고 생각했는데 아무도 좋아해 주지 않으면, 아무 일도 없어요. 다음 날 다른 영상을 올리면 되고, 손볼 것도 없고 그냥 끝이에요 — 마치 그런 일이 전혀 없었던 것처럼 잊혀져요.
text_zh: 我觉得市场营销完全相反。什么成本都没有，什么维护都不用，没有技术难度，什么都没有。比如说我明天在Wiz的领英页面上发个视频，我觉得这视频超搞笑，结果没人点赞，那又怎么样呢？明天我再发个别的视频就行了，不用维护什么，拜拜，当没发过。
text_es: El marketing es todo lo contrario, en mi opinión. No hay costo de nada, no hay mantenimiento de nada, no hay complejidad técnica, no hay nada. Si mañana subo un video en la página de LinkedIn de Wiz, y a mí me parece súper gracioso ese video, y a nadie le gusta, no pasa nada. Mañana subo otro video diferente, sin mantenimiento, chao, como si nunca hubiera pasado.
context: Lenny asks about Raaz's approach to creating noise and taking risks in marketing. Raaz contrasts marketing with product development, explaining how product features require careful consideration because they consume engineering resources and create permanent complexity. She describes marketing's advantage of being able to experiment freely without long-term consequences, allowing for rapid testing and iteration.
vocabulary_highlights: no technical depth, bye-bye, forgot it ever happened

speaker: Raaz Herzberg
speaker_expertise: Product Management, B2B SaaS, Marketing Strategy
text: Almost every single thing I've done in my career, in some ways, even before, I never thought I was going to be successful in it. I guess there's a lot of times, it's a lot of talk about being more confident than yourself. I don't know, at least for me, I don't really know if that's a real option, okay? I just know that I'm kind of okay with being pretty sure I'm going to fail at something, and still attempting it.
text_ko: 제 경력에서 해온 거의 모든 일들, 심지어 그 전의 일들도 어떤 면에선 제가 성공할 거라고 생각해본 적이 거의 없어요. 사람들한테는 자기 자신보다 더 자신감을 가지라는 얘기가 많지만, 솔직히 제겐 그게 현실적인 선택인지 잘 모르겠어요. 저는 오히려 뭔가 실패할 가능성이 꽤 높다고 확신해도, 그래도 시도하는 편이에요.
text_zh: 我职业生涯做过的几乎每一件事，甚至更早的时候，我从来没觉得自己会成功。大家总是说要对自己更有信心，但说实话，至少对我来说，我不太确定这真的管用。我只知道，即使我很可能会搞砸，我也还是愿意去试试。
text_es: Prácticamente todo lo que he hecho en mi carrera, de alguna manera, incluso desde antes, nunca pensé que iba a tener éxito. Supongo que muchas veces se habla mucho de tener más confianza en uno mismo. No sé, al menos para mí, no sé si eso realmente es una opción, ¿sabes? Lo que sí sé es que estoy bastante tranquilo con estar casi seguro de que voy a fracasar en algo, y aun así intentarlo.
context: Lenny asks Raaz about her mindset regarding failure and risk-taking throughout her career. Raaz shares her contrarian approach to confidence and imposter syndrome. Rather than trying to build false confidence, she embraces the expectation of failure while still taking on challenging opportunities. She explains how this mindset actually liberates her to take bigger risks and attempt things outside her comfort zone.
vocabulary_highlights: pretty sure I'm going to fail

speaker: Raaz Herzberg
speaker_expertise: Product Management, B2B SaaS, Marketing Strategy
text: Every time you write something, I wanted to not assume knowledge about Wiz, or knowledge about the product, or deep knowledge about the market. I'll give just a simple example. Wiz itself is based on, part of the deep innovation that Wiz brought to the market that enabled the scale, was a very high correlated signal that's based on a graph database. So inside Wiz, we have the Wiz graph database, for security. If you write something that says, the Wiz Graph Database, I don't like it. Because why would a common person know it is the Wiz Graph Database, right?
text_ko: 무언가를 쓸 때마다 독자가 Wiz를 알고 있다고 가정하거나 제품이나 시장에 대해 깊이 아는 사람이라고 생각하고 싶지 않았어요. 간단한 예를 하나 들게요. Wiz 자체가, 그리고 Wiz가 시장에 가져온 깊은 혁신의 일부는—확장을 가능하게 한 핵심은—그래프 데이터베이스(graph database)를 기반으로 한 상관성이 매우 높은 신호(highly correlated signal)였어요. 그래서 Wiz 안에는 보안용으로 Wiz 그래프 데이터베이스(Wiz Graph Database)가 있어요. 만약 글에 그냥 'The Wiz Graph Database'라고만 쓰면 저는 좋아하지 않아요. 보통 사람이 그게 Wiz 그래프 데이터베이스라는 걸 왜 알겠어요?
text_zh: 每次你写东西的时候，我希望你不要假设别人了解Wiz，或者了解我们的产品，或者对这个市场有很深的了解。我举个简单的例子。Wiz本身基于一个很核心的创新，这个创新让Wiz能够做到现在的规模，就是基于图数据库(graph database)的高相关性信号。所以在Wiz内部，我们有专门用于安全的Wiz图数据库(Wiz Graph Database)。如果你写东西直接说"Wiz图数据库(Wiz Graph Database)"，我不喜欢这样。因为普通人怎么会知道什么是Wiz图数据库(Wiz Graph Database)，对吧？
text_es: Cada vez que escribas algo, quería que no dieras por sentado que la gente conoce Wiz, o que conoce el producto, o que tiene conocimiento profundo del mercado. Te voy a dar un ejemplo sencillo. Wiz en sí está basado en, parte de la innovación profunda que Wiz trajo al mercado y que permitió la escala, fue una señal altamente correlacionada que se basa en una base de datos de grafos (graph database). Entonces dentro de Wiz, tenemos la base de datos de grafos de Wiz, para seguridad. Si escribes algo que dice "la Base de Datos de Grafos de Wiz", no me gusta. Porque ¿por qué una persona común va a saber que es la Base de Datos de Grafos de Wiz, ¿verdad?
context: Lenny asks about Raaz's concept of the 'dummy explanation' and how to avoid assuming too much knowledge in marketing communications. Raaz explains her philosophy of avoiding insider jargon and technical terminology that only people within the company would understand. She gives a specific example of how even mentioning their own 'Wiz Graph Database' assumes knowledge that external audiences wouldn't have, emphasizing the need to communicate in universally understandable terms.
vocabulary_highlights: assume knowledge, deep innovation, high correlated signal

speaker: Rachel Lockett
text: Most leaders, especially technical leaders, assume they have to have all the answers. People have climbed the ladder because they've been dependable, reliable, the smartest person in the room. But great leaders know that when you try to advise and have the answer all the time, you're not actually equipping your team to go solve the hard problems. You're training your team to come to you with all of the hard problems.
text_ko: 대부분의 리더들, 특히 기술 리더(technical leaders)는 모든 답을 가지고 있어야 한다고 생각해요. 사람들은 믿음직하고 신뢰할 수 있고, 회의에서 제일 똑똑한 사람이라서 승진해 온 경우가 많죠. 그런데 훌륭한 리더들은 항상 조언해 주고 정답을 알려주려 하면 팀이 스스로 어려운 문제를 해결할 능력을 키우는 게 아니란 걸 알아요. 오히려 팀을 모든 어려운 문제를 들고 리더에게 오도록 길들이는 거예요.
text_zh: 大多数领导，特别是技术出身的领导，总觉得自己得什么都懂，什么问题都要有答案。他们之所以能爬到今天这个位置，就是因为靠谱、可靠，总是房间里最聪明的那个人。但真正厉害的领导知道，如果你总是试图给建议、给答案，其实你并没有在培养团队解决难题的能力。你这样做，实际上是在训练你的团队——遇到任何难题都来找你。
text_es: La mayoría de los líderes, sobre todo los técnicos, creen que tienen que tener todas las respuestas. La gente ha subido en la empresa porque ha sido confiable, el más inteligente del grupo. Pero los grandes líderes saben que cuando tratas de aconsejar y dar la respuesta todo el tiempo, en realidad no estás preparando a tu equipo para que resuelva los problemas difíciles. Lo que estás haciendo es entrenar a tu equipo para que venga a ti con todos los problemas complicados.
context: Lenny asks Rachel about the biggest gap that keeps leaders from being successful. Rachel explains that many technical leaders believe they must have all the answers because they've advanced in their careers by being the smartest person in the room. However, this approach backfires at scale - constantly providing solutions doesn't develop team capability, it creates dependency where everyone brings problems to the leader instead of solving them independently.
vocabulary_highlights: climbed the ladder, dependable, equipping your team, hard problems

speaker: Rachel Lockett
text: People, when they want to have a conflict, they come in ready to prove their point. There's a misguided view that the goal is to convince the other person that what they're doing is wrong. Actually, the goal of any conflict is to create mutual understanding.
text_ko: 사람들은 갈등을 하려고 하면 자기 주장을 증명하려고 들어요. 상대를 설득해서 그 사람이 틀렸다는 걸 입증하는 게 목표라는 잘못된 생각을 하는 경우가 많은데요. 사실 갈등의 진짜 목적은 상대를 이기거나 틀렸다고 몰아붙이는 게 아니라 서로의 관점을 이해하는 것, 즉 상호 이해(mutual understanding)를 만드는 거예요.
text_zh: 人们一旦想要发生冲突的时候，都是带着证明自己观点的心态来的。大家都有个误区，觉得目标就是要说服对方，让对方承认自己做错了。其实呢，任何冲突的真正目标应该是达成相互理解。
text_es: Cuando la gente quiere entrar en conflicto, llega con ganas de demostrar que tiene razón. Hay una idea equivocada de que el objetivo es convencer al otro de que lo que está haciendo está mal. En realidad, el objetivo de cualquier conflicto debería ser crear un entendimiento mutuo.
context: Lenny asks Rachel how to make difficult conversations less difficult. Rachel explains that most people approach conflict with the wrong mindset - they enter conversations armored and focused on proving their point or convincing others they're wrong. She argues this is fundamentally misguided because productive conflict should aim for mutual understanding rather than winning or being right.
vocabulary_highlights: ready to prove their point, misguided view, mutual understanding

speaker: Rachel Lockett
text: When people are in their gifts and their strengths, they have more energy. We all have more energy when we're operating from the things we naturally are good at. It's no one else's job to help you live in your gifts. What I notice in big companies is people are often annoyed or frustrated with their management for not making their job more interesting. No, your manager's job is to help you perform in the job you are hired to do. It's your job to navigate your career.
text_ko: 사람들이 자기 강점(strengths)과 재능(gifts)을 발휘할 때 에너지가 더 생겨요. 자연스럽게 잘하는 일을 할 때 우리 모두 훨씬 활력이 나요. 자신의 재능을 살려 살도록 돕는 건 다른 사람의 일이 아니에요. 큰 회사에서 제가 자주 보는 건, 사람들이 일을 더 흥미롭게 만들어 주지 않는다고 상사나 관리자에게 짜증 내거나 답답해하는 경우가 많다는 거예요. 하지만 매니저의 역할은 당신이 채용된 그 일을 잘 수행할 수 있게 도와주는 것이고, 자신의 경력을 설계하고 관리하는 것(navigate your career)은 결국 본인의 책임이에요.
text_zh: 当人们发挥自己的天赋和优势时，他们会更有精力。我们做自己天生擅长的事情时，都会更有劲儿。帮你发挥天赋不是别人的活儿。我发现在大公司里，员工经常对管理层有怨言，觉得他们没有让自己的工作变得更有意思。不对，你经理的职责是帮你把招你进来要做的工作做好。规划自己的职业发展，那是你自己的事儿。
text_es: Cuando las personas trabajan desde sus talentos naturales y fortalezas, tienen mucha más energía. Todos tenemos más energía cuando hacemos las cosas para las que somos buenos por naturaleza. Nadie más tiene la responsabilidad de ayudarte a vivir desde tus dones. Lo que veo en las empresas grandes es que la gente a menudo está molesta o frustrada con sus jefes porque no hacen su trabajo más interesante. No, el trabajo de tu manager es ayudarte a rendir en el puesto para el que te contrataron. Tu trabajo es manejar tu propia carrera profesional.
context: Lenny asks about Rachel's advice for helping leaders avoid burnout. Rachel shares her core philosophy that people have more energy when operating in their natural strengths and gifts. She emphasizes personal accountability, pointing out that employees often wrongly expect managers to make their jobs more engaging, when actually it's each person's responsibility to align their career with their strengths over time.
vocabulary_highlights: in their gifts, naturally are good at, navigate your career
topics: Career Development, Work-Life Balance, Leadership & Management

speaker: Rachel Lockett
text: I think that most leaders, especially technical leaders, assume they have to have all the answers. People have climbed the ladder in whatever realm they're in because they've been dependable, reliable, the smartest person in the room. But when you're leading a quickly-scaling company, you quickly have less context than the people you're around. And the way you were operating before doesn't work because you don't have the ability to wrap your arms around every problem in a deep way.
text_ko: 대부분의 리더들, 특히 기술 리더들(technical leaders)은 자기가 모든 답을 다 알고 있어야 한다고 생각하는 경우가 많아요. 각자 분야에서 책임감 있고 신뢰받는, 방에서 제일 똑똑한 사람이었기 때문에 그 자리까지 올라왔으니까요. 그런데 빠르게 확장하는 회사(scaling company)를 이끌다 보면 오히려 주변 사람들보다 맥락을 덜 알게 되는 일이 빠르게 벌어져요. 그래서 예전처럼 모든 문제를 깊게 껴안고 다 해결하던 방식은 더 이상 통하지 않아요 — 모든 문제를 깊이 파악해서 다 처리할 수 있는 여건이 아니거든요.
text_zh: 我觉得大部分领导，特别是技术出身的领导，都觉得自己必须什么都懂，什么问题都得有答案。这些人之所以能一步步爬到今天这个位置，就是因为他们一直都很靠谱，是房间里最聪明的那个人。但是当你在管理一个快速扩张的公司时，你很快就会发现，周围的人比你更了解具体情况。以前那套管理方式就不好使了，因为你根本没办法深入了解每一个问题的方方面面。
text_es: Creo que la mayoría de los líderes, especialmente los técnicos, asumen que tienen que tener todas las respuestas. La gente ha subido peldaños en su área porque ha sido confiable, de fiar, la más inteligente del grupo. Pero cuando estás liderando una empresa que crece rapidísimo, de repente tienes menos contexto que la gente que te rodea. Y la forma en que operabas antes ya no funciona porque no puedes abarcar cada problema a fondo como antes.
context: Rachel elaborates on why the traditional approach of having all the answers fails at scale. She explains that while technical leaders advanced by being reliable and knowledgeable, at rapidly growing companies they actually have less context than their team members. The old approach becomes impossible because leaders can't deeply understand every problem when the company scales.
vocabulary_highlights: wrap your arms around, in a deep way, quickly-scaling

speaker: Rachel Lockett
text: What I notice in big companies is people are often annoyed or frustrated with their management for not making their job more interesting. No, your manager's job is to help you perform in the job you are hired to do. It's your job to navigate your career.
text_ko: 대기업에서 제가 볼 때, 사람들은 자기 일을 더 재밌게 만들어주지 않는 관리자(manager) 때문에 짜증 나거나 답답해하는 경우가 많아요. 하지만 매니저(manager)의 역할은 당신이 채용된 업무를 잘 수행할 수 있도록 돕는 거예요. 자신의 커리어(career)를 어떻게 설계하고 이끌어갈지는 본인의 몫이에요.
text_zh: 我发现在大公司里，很多人都抱怨自己的领导不给他们安排更有意思的工作，觉得很烦躁。其实不是这样的，你老板的职责是帮你把现在的工作做好，而规划职业发展这事儿，得你自己来。
text_es: Lo que veo en las empresas grandes es que la gente a menudo está molesta o frustrada con sus jefes porque no hacen su trabajo más interesante. No, el trabajo de tu manager es ayudarte a rendir bien en el puesto para el que te contrataron. Tu trabajo es manejar tu propia carrera profesional.
context: In discussing burnout prevention, Rachel addresses a common misconception she observes in large companies. Many employees expect their managers to make their roles more engaging or interesting, but Rachel clarifies that managers are responsible for helping people succeed in their current role, while career navigation and finding fulfilling work is each individual's personal responsibility.
vocabulary_highlights: navigate your career

speaker: Rachel Lockett
text: So I try to help my leaders see that they can design their lives so they're spending 80% of their time in their gifts. That seems really ambitious because you're stuck within a context that requires a lot of you. Especially when you're executive at a huge company. But I also interact with founders who started a company with great inspiration, an entrepreneurial vision, and their job has obviously changed every six months.
text_ko: 그래서 저는 리더들이 자신의 삶을 설계해서 시간의 80%를 자기 강점(gifts)을 발휘하는 데 쓸 수 있다는 걸 보도록 도와드려요. 많은 걸 요구하는 환경 안에 갇혀 있으면 그게 굉장히 야심차게 들릴 수 있어요. 특히 대기업의 임원이라면 더 그렇죠. 하지만 저는 큰 영감과 창업가적 비전으로 회사를 시작한 창업자들과도 자주 만나는데, 그분들은 역할이 6개월마다 확실히 바뀌는 게 당연하다고 느껴요.
text_zh: 所以我会帮助我的领导者意识到，他们可以规划自己的生活，让80%的时间都花在发挥自己天赋上。这听起来很有挑战性，因为你被困在一个对你要求很高的环境里，特别是当你在大公司当高管的时候。但我也接触过一些创始人，他们当初带着很棒的灵感和创业愿景创立公司，但他们的工作内容显然每六个月就在变化。
text_es: Entonces trato de ayudar a mis líderes a que vean que pueden diseñar sus vidas para dedicar el 80% de su tiempo a lo que realmente se les da bien, a sus fortalezas. Suena súper ambicioso porque estás atrapado en un contexto que te exige muchísimo. Sobre todo cuando eres ejecutivo en una empresa enorme. Pero también trabajo con fundadores que empezaron su empresa con una inspiración increíble, con una visión emprendedora, y obviamente su trabajo ha cambiado cada seis meses.
context: Rachel discusses helping leaders avoid burnout by operating in their strengths most of the time. She acknowledges this 80% goal seems ambitious given organizational constraints, especially for executives at large companies. She notes that founders face a particular challenge because their roles evolve dramatically as companies scale, often moving them away from the work that originally inspired them to start the business.
vocabulary_highlights: design their lives, in their gifts, entrepreneurial vision
topics: Career Development, Leadership & Management, Work-Life Balance

speaker: Rahul Vohra
speaker_expertise: Product Management, User Experience, Growth Strategy
text: You have to deliberately not act on the feedback of many of your early users, and this is at the same time as listening to people intensely and building what people want. That's what we're here to do, is to make something that people want, but it can't be all people. And the question becomes, how do you listen to them? And then even of what they say, what do you pay attention to and what don't you?
text_ko: 초기 사용자(early users) 여러 명의 피드백(feedback)에 대해서는 일부러 전부 따르지 않아야 해요. 동시에 사람들 얘기를 집중해서 듣고, 사람들이 진짜 원하는 걸 만들어야 해요. 그게 우리가 하는 일이에요 — 사람들이 원하는 걸 만드는 거죠. 하지만 모든 사람을 만족시킬 순 없어요. 그래서 관건은 어떻게 그들의 얘기를 듣느냐이고, 그들이 말한 것 중 무엇에 주목하고 무엇을 흘려보낼지 결정하는 거예요.
text_zh: 你得故意不按早期用户的很多反馈去做，但同时又要认真听取大家的意见，做出用户想要的产品。我们的目标就是做出用户喜欢的东西，但不可能满足所有人。关键问题是，你怎么听取用户意见？然后就算听了，哪些该重视，哪些该忽略？
text_es: Tienes que decidir conscientemente no hacer caso al feedback de muchos de tus primeros usuarios, y esto al mismo tiempo que escuchas intensamente a la gente y construyes lo que la gente quiere. Para eso estamos aquí, para hacer algo que la gente quiera, pero no puede ser para toda la gente. Y la pregunta es: ¿cómo les haces caso? Y luego, de todo lo que te dicen, ¿a qué le prestas atención y a qué no?
context: Lenny asks Rahul about what people still don't understand about finding product market fit. Rahul explains one of the key counterintuitive insights from building Superhuman - that reaching product market fit requires deliberately ignoring feedback from certain user segments while intensely listening to others. He emphasizes that you can't build something that works for everyone, so the critical skill is knowing which feedback to act on and which to disregard.
vocabulary_highlights: deliberately not act on, intensely, pay attention to

speaker: Rahul Vohra
speaker_expertise: Product Management, User Experience, Growth Strategy
text: This is a technique that I call the switch lock. It's born out of the observation that your calendar says what you thought you were going to do, but it's really only your trail of work that describes what you actually did. How can we capture that? So I came up with the following idea. What if I just did whatever the heck I wanted?
text_ko: 이건 제가 '스위치 락(switch lock)'이라고 부르는 기법이에요. 캘린더에는 계획해둔 일들이 적혀 있지만, 실제로 무엇을 했는지는 오히려 작업 흔적(trail of work)만이 보여줘요. 그걸 어떻게 포착할 수 있을까요? 그래서 저는 이런 아이디어를 떠올렸어요. 그냥 하고 싶은 대로 다 해버리면 어떨까요?
text_zh: 这个方法我叫它"切换锁定"(switch lock)。我发现一个现象，就是你的日程表只能说明你当时打算做什么，但真正能反映你实际干了什么的，其实是你的工作轨迹。那怎么才能抓住这个规律呢？所以我就想出了这么个点子：要不我就完全按自己的意思来，想干嘛就干嘛？
text_es: Esta es una técnica que yo llamo el "cambio de cerradura" (switch lock). Nace de la observación de que tu agenda dice lo que pensabas que ibas a hacer, pero en realidad solo tu rastro de trabajo describe lo que realmente hiciste. ¿Cómo podemos capturar eso? Entonces se me ocurrió la siguiente idea. ¿Y si simplemente hiciera lo que se me diera la gana?
context: Lenny asks Rahul about his detailed time tracking system that helped him realize he was only spending 6-7% of his time on product, design, and marketing. Rahul describes his "Switch Log" technique, where instead of being constrained by calendar appointments, he tracks what he actually works on by messaging his assistant every time he changes tasks. This system revealed the gap between planned work and actual work, leading to organizational changes that improved his focus.
vocabulary_highlights: born out of the observation, trail of work, whatever the heck I wanted

speaker: Rahul Vohra
speaker_expertise: Product Management, User Experience, Growth Strategy
text: There is no such thing as a truly viral product. What I mean is, no app has sustained a viral factor of greater than one for any real period of time. Even Facebook in its heyday had a viral factor of about 0.7. It is word of mouth. It is the virality you can't measure that isn't a mechanic that isn't in a feature. It is when one user spontaneously tells another user about your product.
text_ko: 진정한 바이럴 제품(viral product)이라는 건 없어요. 제 말은 어떤 앱도 장기간 동안 바이럴 팩터(viral factor)가 1을 넘는 상태를 유지한 적이 없다는 거예요. 전성기의 페이스북조차 바이럴 팩터가 대략 0.7 정도였어요. 결국은 입소문(word of mouth)이에요. 특정 기능(메커니즘)으로 측정되는 게 아니라 측정하기 힘든 바이럴성(virality)이에요. 한 사용자가 자발적으로 다른 사용자에게 당신의 제품을 알려줄 때 그게 바로 그거예요.
text_zh: 其实根本就没有什么真正意义上的病毒式传播(viral)产品。我的意思是，没有任何一个App能够长期保持病毒传播系数(viral factor)大于1的状态。就连Facebook在最辉煌的时候，病毒传播系数也就0.7左右。真正起作用的是口碑传播，是那种你没法量化的自然传播，不是什么机制，也不是什么功能特性。就是一个用户自发地跟另一个用户聊起你的产品，就这么简单。
text_es: No existe tal cosa como un producto verdaderamente viral. Lo que quiero decir es que ninguna app ha mantenido un factor viral mayor a uno por un período real de tiempo. Incluso Facebook en su mejor momento tenía un factor viral de como 0.7. Es el boca a boca. Es esa viralidad que no puedes medir, que no es una mecánica, que no está en una funcionalidad. Es cuando un usuario espontáneamente le cuenta a otro usuario sobre tu producto.
context: Lenny asks Rahul about the secret to virality that he learned from Elliot Shmukler, LinkedIn's head of Growth. Rahul shares the counterintuitive insight that no product actually sustains true viral growth (where one user creates more than one new user) for extended periods. Instead, the real driver of sustainable growth is organic word of mouth - when users spontaneously recommend your product to others because they genuinely love it, not because of built-in viral mechanics.
vocabulary_highlights: viral factor, in its heyday, spontaneously

speaker: Rahul Vohra
speaker_expertise: Product Management, User Experience, Growth Strategy
text: You can classify anything that you build in a company into one of two categories, solution deepening and market widening. Solution deepening means making your product better for its existing users, but not making it available to more users. Whereas market widening means making your product available to more users, but not making the product itself any better.
text_ko: 회사가 만드는 모든 것은 두 가지로 분류할 수 있어요: 솔루션 고도화(solution deepening)와 시장 확장(market widening). 솔루션 고도화는 기존 사용자에게 제품을 더 좋게 만드는 것이지만 더 많은 사용자에게 제공하진 않는다는 뜻이에요. 반면 시장 확장은 제품 자체를 더 개선하진 않고 더 많은 사용자에게 제품을 닿게 하는 걸 말해요.
text_zh: 公司里做的事情基本上可以分成两类：一个是深挖解决方案，一个是拓宽市场。深挖解决方案就是让现有用户用得更爽，但不会增加新用户。拓宽市场呢，就是让更多人能用上你的产品，但产品本身没什么提升。
text_es: Todo lo que construyes en una empresa lo puedes clasificar en dos categorías: profundización de la solución (solution deepening) y ampliación del mercado (market widening). La profundización de la solución significa mejorar tu producto para los usuarios que ya tienes, pero sin hacerlo disponible para más gente. Mientras que la ampliación del mercado significa hacer tu producto disponible para más usuarios, pero sin mejorar el producto en sí.
context: Lenny asks Rahul what changed at Superhuman that made their product velocity feel faster. Rahul explains the difference between avoidable and unavoidable slowdowns. He introduces his framework for categorizing product development work: solution deepening (improving the product for current users) versus market widening (expanding to new user segments or platforms). Understanding this distinction helps explain why companies sometimes appear to slow down when they're actually doing necessary work to expand their market.
vocabulary_highlights: solution deepening, market widening

speaker: Rahul Vohra
speaker_expertise: Product Management, User Experience, Growth Strategy
text: The very presence of a reward halved their motivation. So what's happening? What's happening here, is researchers differentiate intrinsic motivation and extrinsic motivation. With intrinsic motivation we do things because they are inherently interesting and satisfying, and with extrinsic motivation, we do things to earn rewards and to achieve external goals. That's the problem with rewards, is they just massively undermine intrinsic motivation.
text_ko: 보상(reward)이 있다는 사실만으로도 그들의 동기가 절반으로 줄어들었어요. 그렇다면 무슨 일이 일어나는 걸까요? 핵심은 연구자들이 내적 동기(intrinsic motivation)와 외적 동기(extrinsic motivation)를 구분한다는 거예요. 내적 동기일 때는 그 행동 자체가 본질적으로 흥미롭고 만족스럽기 때문에 스스로 하게 되고, 외적 동기일 때는 보상을 얻거나 외부의 목표를 달성하기 위해 행동해요. 문제는 바로 보상인데, 보상은 내적 동기를 엄청나게 약화시켜 버린다는 거예요.
text_zh: 光是有奖励这件事，就让他们的积极性直接减半了。这是怎么回事呢？研究人员把动机分成两种：内在动机(intrinsic motivation)和外在动机(extrinsic motivation)。内在动机就是我们做事情是因为这事本身就有意思、有成就感；外在动机呢，就是为了拿奖励、达成外部目标才去做。奖励的问题就在这儿——它们会严重打击内在动机。
text_es: El simple hecho de que hubiera una recompensa les redujo la motivación a la mitad. ¿Qué está pasando aquí? Lo que pasa es que los investigadores distinguen entre la motivación intrínseca y la motivación extrínseca. Con la motivación intrínseca hacemos las cosas porque nos resultan interesantes y satisfactorias por sí mismas, y con la motivación extrínseca hacemos las cosas para ganar recompensas y lograr objetivos externos. Ahí está el problema con las recompensas: que socavan tremendamente la motivación intrínseca.
context: Lenny asks Rahul about the difference between game design and gamification in product development. Rahul shares research from Stanford showing how external rewards can actually decrease motivation in children who were already interested in drawing. This study demonstrates why adding points, badges, and rewards (gamification) often fails - because external rewards undermine people's intrinsic motivation to engage with an activity they might naturally enjoy.
vocabulary_highlights: halved their motivation, inherently interesting, massively undermine

speaker: Rahul Vohra
speaker_expertise: Product Management, User Experience, Growth Strategy
text: For important decisions, you should be able to identify one, one reason that on its own supports the decision. It's based on the observation that all too often we rely on a collection of weak reasons to justify decisions. If they can't yet isolate it, that tells me they haven't yet figured out why they want to make the decision.
text_ko: 중요한 결정을 할 때는 그 결정을 단독으로 뒷받침할 수 있는 딱 한 가지 이유를 말할 수 있어야 해요. 이건 우리가 너무 자주 약한 근거들을 여러 개 모아 결정을 정당화하곤 한다는 관찰에 근거한 말이에요. 만약 그 한 가지를 아직 못 집어낸다면, 그건 그들이 왜 그 결정을 하려는지(또는 내려야 하는지)를 아직 스스로 명확히 파악하지 못했다는 뜻이에요.
text_zh: 做重要决定的时候，你得能找出一个真正站得住脚的核心理由，光这一个理由就足以支撑整个决定。我发现很多时候大家都是拿一堆不痛不痒的小理由来给决定找借口。如果他们还说不出那个最关键的点在哪儿，那说明他们自己都没想明白为什么要这么做。
text_es: Para decisiones importantes, deberías poder identificar una sola razón que por sí sola justifique la decisión. Esto se basa en que muy seguido nos apoyamos en un montón de razones débiles para justificar lo que decidimos. Si no pueden aislar esa razón principal, eso me dice que aún no tienen claro por qué quieren tomar esa decisión.
context: Lenny asks Rahul about his "Single Decisive Reason" (SDR) framework for decision-making. Rahul explains this technique he learned from Reid Hoffman at LinkedIn, where for any important decision, you must identify one reason that alone justifies the choice. This prevents people from using multiple weak arguments to support decisions and forces clearer thinking about what truly drives a choice.
vocabulary_highlights: on its own, collection of weak reasons, isolate it

speaker: Ramesh Johari
text: So what we decided to do is build some custom bespoke features that were really going to direct them to more experienced folks on the other side of the market. Good. And then, yeah, lo and behold, pretty soon those metrics start to look better. But then we're looking at it, we're like, "Wait a second. Now the existing folks on the other side are having a worse experience," so you kind of whiplash around.
text_ko: 그래서 저희는 시장 반대편에 있는 더 경험 많은 분들로 진짜로 연결해 줄 맞춤형 기능(custom bespoke features)을 몇 가지 만들기로 했어요. 그리고 얼마 지나지 않아 지표(metrics)가 좋아지기 시작했죠. 그런데 살펴보니, 잠깐만요, 반대편에 있던 기존 사용자들의 경험은 오히려 나빠지고 있더라고요. 그래서 저희가 이랬다저랬다 하게 된 거예요.
text_zh: 所以我们就决定搞一些定制化的功能，专门把他们导向到市场另一边那些更有经验的人那里去。效果不错。然后你猜怎么着，很快那些指标数据就开始好看起来了。但是我们一看，就发现"等等，现在市场另一边那些老用户的体验反而变差了"，这样一来就像坐过山车一样，左摇右摆的。
text_es: Entonces lo que decidimos hacer fue crear algunas funciones personalizadas a medida que realmente iban a dirigirlos hacia gente más experimentada del otro lado del mercado. Perfecto. Y luego, sí, como era de esperarse, muy pronto esas métricas empezaron a verse mejor. Pero después estamos viendo todo esto y pensamos, "Un momento. Ahora los usuarios que ya estaban del otro lado están teniendo una experiencia peor," entonces como que te das cuenta de que estás dando bandazos de un lado para otro.
context: Ramesh is explaining how marketplace management is like a game of whac-a-mole, using an example from a company he worked with. The team noticed their new supply side was having a poor experience, so they built custom features to connect them with more experienced users on the demand side. While this improved metrics for new users, it created problems for existing users who now had worse experiences. This illustrates how changes in marketplaces often create winners and losers rather than improving everything universally.
vocabulary_highlights: custom bespoke features, lo and behold, whiplash around

speaker: Ramesh Johari
text: The most important one is this. What I've found talking to people who want to start what they think is a marketplace is that they think too much about a marketplace before they're a marketplace. That in my view is the biggest failure mode.
text_ko: 가장 중요한 건 이거예요. 제가 마켓플레이스(marketplace)를 시작하려는 사람들과 얘기해보면, 정작 마켓플레이스가 되기도 전에 마켓플레이스에 대해 너무 많이 생각해요. 제 생각엔 그게 가장 큰 실패 유형(failure mode)이에요.
text_zh: 最重要的一点是这个。我发现那些想做marketplace的人，他们还没成为marketplace之前，就想得太多了。在我看来，这是最容易栽跟头的地方。
text_es: Lo más importante es esto. Lo que he visto hablando con gente que quiere crear lo que creen que es un marketplace es que se obsesionan demasiado con ser un marketplace antes de serlo realmente. Esa para mí es la forma más común de fracasar.
context: Lenny asks Ramesh about common flaws when founders try to start marketplace businesses, noting that certain types like cleaners or car wash marketplaces often fail. Ramesh explains that the biggest mistake founders make is focusing too early on marketplace dynamics before they have the scale and liquidity to actually function as a marketplace. He believes founders should first solve immediate problems and build one side of the market before worrying about marketplace mechanics.
vocabulary_highlights: failure mode

speaker: Ramesh Johari
text: So in their example, as they evolved, they actually shifted their monetization model away from billing specifically for this friction of allowing you to pay with credit cards, instead to now billing for how you were interviewing and contacting sitters. They had a two-part plan for that. One with a pay as you go menu, one with a more of a subscription option.
text_ko: 그들의 사례에서는 서비스가 진화하면서 수익화 모델(monetization model)을 바꿨어요. 원래는 신용카드로 결제하게 해 주는 데서 생기는 마찰(friction)에 대해 따로 과금했는데, 나중에는 시터와 인터뷰하고 연락하는 방식 자체에 대해 과금하는 쪽으로 전환했어요. 그걸 위해 두 가지 계획을 세웠는데, 하나는 사용한 만큼 지불(pay-as-you-go)하는 메뉴이고, 다른 하나는 구독(subscription)형 옵션이었어요.
text_zh: 拿他们的例子来说，随着业务发展，他们其实调整了变现模式(monetization model)，不再专门针对信用卡支付这个痛点收费，而是改为按你面试和联系保姆的次数来收费。他们搞了个两套方案：一个是按次付费的套餐，另一个是订阅制(subscription)的选择。
text_es: Entonces en su ejemplo, conforme fueron evolucionando, en realidad cambiaron su modelo de monetización y dejaron de cobrar específicamente por esa fricción de permitirte pagar con tarjetas de crédito, para ahora cobrar por cómo entrevistabas y contactabas a las niñeras. Tenían un plan de dos partes para eso: uno con un menú de pago por uso (pay as you go), y otro más tipo suscripción.
context: Ramesh is discussing UrbanSitter as an example of how successful marketplaces don't start as marketplaces. UrbanSitter initially solved a simple problem - allowing parents to pay babysitters with credit cards instead of cash. As they grew and built network effects through Facebook connections, they evolved their business model to charge for the core marketplace function of helping parents find and contact babysitters, rather than just payment processing.
vocabulary_highlights: pay as you go menu

speaker: Ramesh Johari
text: So when you start, you had better be thinking, "What's my value proposition in a world in which I don't have that scaled liquidity on both sides?" And that's bespoke. It means different things.
text_ko: 그래서 시작할 때는 “양측에서의 규모화된 유동성(scaled liquidity on both sides)이 없는 세상에서 내 가치 제안(value proposition)은 뭐지?”라고 생각해봐야 해요. 그건 맞춤형(bespoke)이어서 경우마다 의미가 달라요.
text_zh: 所以刚开始的时候，你最好想清楚一个问题："在我还没有双边规模化流动性的情况下，我的价值主张(value proposition)到底是什么？" 这个问题因人而异，每家公司的答案都不一样。
text_es: Entonces cuando empiezas, más te vale preguntarte: "¿Cuál es mi propuesta de valor (value proposition) en un mundo donde no tengo esa liquidez escalada de ambos lados?" Y eso es algo muy específico para cada caso. Significa cosas distintas.
context: Ramesh is explaining why marketplace businesses never start as marketplace businesses. He argues that when you're starting out, you don't have the scale and liquidity on both sides that makes a marketplace valuable. Therefore, founders need to identify what unique value they can provide before they have that marketplace scale. This value proposition will be customized and specific to each business situation.
vocabulary_highlights: scaled liquidity, that's bespoke

speaker: Ramesh Johari
text: So one thing you said was, "That's what you tell marketplace founders." I mean, something I've actually pressed hard on in my own way of thinking about this is that maybe we shouldn't talk about the concept of a marketplace founder. Really there's founders.
text_ko: 그래서 당신이 “그건 마켓플레이스 창업자들(marketplace founders)에게 하는 말이에요”라고 하신 게 하나 있었어요. 제가 이걸 제 방식대로 생각하면서 꽤 강하게 주장해온 건, 어쩌면 ‘마켓플레이스 창업자들(marketplace founders)’이라는 개념 자체를 굳이 얘기할 필요가 없다는 점이에요. 사실 결국엔 그냥 창업자들일 뿐이에요.
text_zh: 你刚才说的"这就是你告诉市场平台创始人的话"，其实我一直在想一个问题，可能我们根本就不应该谈什么市场平台创始人这个概念。说白了，创始人就是创始人。
text_es: Entonces, una cosa que dijiste fue: "Eso es lo que les dices a los fundadores de marketplace." O sea, algo en lo que he insistido mucho en mi forma de pensar esto es que tal vez no deberíamos hablar del concepto de "fundador de marketplace." En realidad lo que hay son fundadores, punto.
context: Lenny mentions that he gives similar advice to marketplace founders about focusing on non-marketplace specific problems. Ramesh pushes back on the very concept of labeling someone as a "marketplace founder." He believes that in today's digital economy, virtually any business could become a platform or marketplace as it scales, so founders shouldn't limit themselves by thinking of themselves specifically as marketplace builders from the start.
vocabulary_highlights: pressed hard on

speaker: Ramesh Johari
text: That meant that the longer that goes on, the less value the platform is adding into that relationship, but you're still pulling 10% of all the dollars. So what does that lead to? A word that most marketplace CEOs know well is disintermediation, which is where you were intermediating between the two parties, and now disintermediation means that essentially they're like, "Hey, we don't need you anymore."
text_ko: 그 말은 시간이 갈수록 플랫폼이 그 관계에 더해주는 가치가 줄어드는데도 여전히 전체 거래액의 10%를 가져간다는 뜻이에요. 그럼 그게 뭐로 이어질까요? 대부분의 마켓플레이스 CEO들이 잘 아는 탈중개(disintermediation) 현상이 생기는데, 원래 두 당사자 사이에서 중개하던 플랫폼을 당사자들이 직접 만나서 거래하면서 “이제 너 필요 없어요”라고 하는 상황이에요.
text_zh: 这就意味着，时间越长，平台在这种关系中创造的价值就越少，但你还是要抽取所有交易金额的10%。那这会导致什么呢？有一个词，大部分平台CEO都很熟悉，叫做去中介化(disintermediation)，就是说你本来是在两方之间做中介的，现在去中介化就是他们基本上会说："嘿，我们不再需要你了。"
text_es: Eso significaba que mientras más tiempo pasara, menos valor agregaba la plataforma a esa relación, pero seguías cobrando el 10% de todo el dinero. Entonces, ¿a qué lleva esto? A una palabra que la mayoría de los CEOs de marketplaces conocen muy bien: desintermediación (disintermediation). O sea, antes tú hacías de intermediario entre las dos partes, pero con la desintermediación básicamente te dicen: "Oye, ya no te necesitamos."
context: Ramesh is explaining how early business model decisions can create problems later for marketplace platforms. Using oDesk (now Upwork) as an example, he describes how their original model of taking a percentage of all transactions worked initially when they were providing monitoring tools. However, as relationships matured and trust developed between workers and employers, the platform was adding less value but still taking the same cut, leading to disintermediation where parties bypass the platform entirely.
vocabulary_highlights: pulling 10% of all the dollars, disintermediation, intermediating

speaker: Ramesh Johari
text: You have to recognize when you run marketplaces that many of the changes that are most consequential create winners and losers. And rolling with those changes is about recognizing whether the winners you've created are more important to your business than the losers you've created in the process.
text_ko: 마켓플레이스(marketplaces)를 운영할 때는, 가장 큰 영향을 미치는 변화들이 종종 승자(winners)와 패자(losers)를 만들어낸다는 걸 알아야 해요. 그리고 그런 변화에 유연하게 대응하는 건, 그 과정에서 생긴 승자들이 만든 패자들보다 당신의 비즈니스에 더 중요한지 판단하는 일이에요.
text_zh: 做平台生意你得明白，很多重大变化都会造成有人得利有人受损。能不能适应这些变化，关键看你创造出来的受益方对你生意的重要性，是不是比那些在过程中利益受损的一方更重要。
text_es: Cuando manejas marketplaces tienes que darte cuenta de que muchos de los cambios más importantes van a crear ganadores y perdedores. Y adaptarte a esos cambios se trata de reconocer si los ganadores que has creado son más importantes para tu negocio que los perdedores que generaste en el proceso.
context: Ramesh is explaining the "whac-a-mole" nature of marketplace management, where fixing problems in one area often creates problems elsewhere. He's sharing a quote from Servaes Tholen, former CFO at Upwork and Thumbtack, about how marketplace changes inevitably create trade-offs. Rather than expecting every change to benefit everyone, successful marketplace operators need to understand and accept that impactful changes will help some users while potentially hurting others, and make strategic decisions about which trade-offs are worth making.
vocabulary_highlights: most consequential, rolling with those changes

speaker: Ravi Mehta
text: The framework I like to use with product leaders that I'm coaching is to think about a matrix. Your ideal goal is to lead in a scalable way, which means you feel really confident about the direction of your team and your team has the autonomy to move in that direction. There's another really effective way of leading, which is selective micromanagement, which if you don't feel confident in the direction that your team is moving, the right answer is not to be hands-off and to let them go in that wrong direction.
text_ko: 제가 코칭하는 프로덕트 리더(product leaders)들에게 제가 좋아하는 프레임워크는 매트릭스(matrix)로 생각하는 방식이에요. 이상적인 목표는 확장 가능한(scalable) 방식으로 리드하는 건데, 그건 팀의 방향에 대해 확신이 있고 팀이 그 방향으로 자율성(autonomy)을 갖고 움직일 수 있는 상태를 말해요. 또 다른 효과적인 리딩 방식은 선택적 마이크로매니지먼트(selective micromanagement)인데, 팀이 어디로 가는지 확신이 서지 않을 때 옳은 답은 손을 놓고 내버려 두는 게 아니에요 — 잘못된 방향으로 가고 있다면 개입해야 해요.
text_zh: 我在指导产品负责人的时候，喜欢用一个矩阵框架来思考这个问题。你的理想目标是做到可扩展的领导方式(scalable leadership)，就是说你对团队的方向很有信心，同时团队也有足够的自主权朝着这个方向前进。还有另一种很有效的领导方式，叫选择性微管理(selective micromanagement)，就是当你对团队前进的方向没把握的时候，正确的做法不是放手不管，让他们朝错误的方向走下去。
text_es: El marco que me gusta usar con los líderes de producto que entreno es pensar en una matriz. Tu objetivo ideal es liderar de manera escalable, lo que significa que te sientes súper seguro sobre la dirección de tu equipo y tu equipo tiene la autonomía para moverse en esa dirección. Hay otra forma muy efectiva de liderar, que es la microgestión selectiva, porque si no te sientes confiado en la dirección que está tomando tu equipo, la respuesta correcta no es quedarte de brazos cruzados y dejar que vayan por el camino equivocado.
context: Lenny asks Ravi about his approach to product leadership and management. Ravi explains his framework for leading product teams, distinguishing between two effective leadership styles. He advocates for "selective micromanagement" as a temporary, tactical approach when teams need direction, rather than being completely hands-off when unsure about team direction.
vocabulary_highlights: scalable way, selective micromanagement, hands-off, move in that direction

speaker: Ravi Mehta
text: There's this common, I would say it's a misconception that startups are faster than larger companies. And what I found initially is actually things felt slower when I started my own company because I didn't have as many engineers to work with. The advantage a smaller company has really is in latency. You can have an idea one day, you can test it the next day, and as a result you can have this really short cycle time between an assumption or a hypothesis and being able to validate that hypothesis.
text_ko: 사실 스타트업이 대기업보다 빠르다는 건 흔한 오해라고 생각해요. 제가 직접 회사를 시작했을 때는 오히려 모든 게 더 느리게 느껴졌어요. 함께 일할 엔지니어가 많지 않아서요. 작은 회사의 진짜 장점은 지연(latency)이 짧다는 거예요. 아이디어가 떠오르면 하루 만에 테스트해볼 수 있고, 그래서 가정(assumption)이나 가설(hypothesis)을 세우고 그것을 검증하는 사이클 타임(cycle time)이 정말 짧아요.
text_zh: 有个很普遍的误区，就是觉得初创公司比大公司动作更快。但我刚开始创业的时候发现，其实感觉上反而更慢了，因为手下的工程师没那么多。小公司真正的优势其实是反应速度快。你今天有个想法，明天就能去测试，所以从有个假设或者猜想，到验证这个假设，整个周期特别短。
text_es: Hay esta idea bastante común, yo diría que es un malentendido, de que las startups son más rápidas que las empresas grandes. Y lo que me di cuenta al principio es que en realidad las cosas se sentían más lentas cuando arranqué mi propia empresa porque no tenía tantos ingenieros con los que trabajar. La ventaja que tiene realmente una empresa más pequeña es en la latencia. Puedes tener una idea un día, la puedes probar al día siguiente, y como resultado puedes tener este ciclo súper corto entre una suposición o una hipótesis y poder validar esa hipótesis.
context: Lenny asks Ravi about the biggest differences between being a product leader at a big company versus starting his own company. Ravi explains a counterintuitive insight about startup speed, distinguishing between velocity (quantity of work) and latency (time from idea to testing). He uses this to explain why startups have advantages in agility rather than raw output.
vocabulary_highlights: misconception, cycle time, validate that hypothesis
topics: Starting a Company, Decision Making, Strategy & Planning

speaker: Ravi Mehta
text: I've had to shift my mindset from an experimental-oriented approach to making decisions to much more of a conviction-oriented approach. And I've often found myself asking the question of like, do we just have enough data to have informed conviction and we should move forward and stop digging, move forward in a particular direction, and then see whether or not that turns out to be the right one?
text_ko: 결정을 내릴 때 실험 중심 접근(experimental-oriented approach)에서 확신 중심 접근(conviction-oriented approach)으로 마음가짐을 많이 바꿔야 했어요. 그래서 자주 스스로에게 “우리가 근거 있는 확신(informed conviction)을 가질 만큼 데이터가 충분한가? 더 파고들지 말고 특정 방향으로 추진해 보고 그게 옳은지 확인해보자”라고 묻곤 해요.
text_zh: 我必须改变思维方式，从以前那种试验性的决策方法转向更多依靠信念的方法。我经常问自己一个问题：我们现在的数据够不够支撑一个有根据的判断？如果够的话，是不是应该停止继续挖掘，直接朝着某个方向推进，然后看看这个选择到底对不对？
text_es: He tenido que cambiar mi mentalidad de un enfoque más experimental para tomar decisiones a uno mucho más basado en convicción. Y me encuentro a menudo preguntándome: ¿tenemos ya suficientes datos para tener una convicción bien fundamentada y deberíamos seguir adelante y dejar de indagar tanto, avanzar en una dirección específica, y después ver si resulta ser la correcta o no?
context: Ravi continues explaining differences between big companies and startups, focusing on decision-making approaches. He describes how startups can't rely on experimental approaches due to limited user bases for statistical significance, requiring instead a conviction-based approach where you gather enough data to make informed decisions quickly rather than getting stuck in analysis paralysis.
vocabulary_highlights: conviction-oriented approach, informed conviction, stop digging

speaker: Ravi Mehta
text: The analogy I like to use, it's a little bit like working with an architect. You would never work with an architect that didn't provide you a blueprint of the house that they want to build for you because being able to describe a house in words alone is not enough. Everyone will come away from that with sort of a different interpretation of what is needed.
text_ko: 제가 자주 드는 비유인데요, 건축가와 함께 일하는 것과 비슷해요. 지어줄 집에 대한 설계도(blueprint)를 보여주지 않는 건축가와는 보통 일하지 않으실 거예요. 말로만 집을 설명하는 건 충분하지 않아요. 사람마다 필요한 걸 다르게 해석하게 되니까요.
text_zh: 我喜欢用的一个比喻，就有点像和建筑师合作。你肯定不会跟一个不给你提供房屋设计图纸的建筑师合作，因为光用嘴说说房子要怎么建是不够的。每个人听完都会有不同的理解，对需求的理解也就不一样了。
text_es: La analogía que me gusta usar es como trabajar with an architect. Nunca trabajarías con un arquitecto que no te dé un plano de la casa que te va a construir, porque describir una casa solo con palabras no es suficiente. Cada quien se va a quedar con una interpretación diferente de lo que se necesita.
context: Lenny asks Ravi about his belief that product visions should be visual rather than just written documents. Ravi explains why wireframes are essential in strategy documents, using an architect analogy to illustrate how visual representations create better alignment than words alone. He argues that since products are ultimately visual (pixels on screen), strategy should include visual elements.
vocabulary_highlights: come away from that, different interpretation
topics: Product Management, Strategy & Planning, Communication Skills

speaker: Ravi Mehta
text: One of the things that I found, which I think was sort of a first principle that's happening at a lot of companies, is this idea of always focusing on outcomes over outputs and comes from a good place, which is ultimately, and I think this is the case, ultimately, a PM needs to measure their success based on whether or not they generate valuable outcomes for the business. But that doesn't necessarily mean that in this quarter we need to commit to a specific outcome or that we should commit to a specific outcome that we may or may not know how to move.
text_ko: 제가 발견한 것 중 하나는, 많은 회사에서 일어나는 일종의 기본 원칙(first principle)처럼 '산출물(outputs)보다 성과(outcomes)에 항상 집중하자'는 생각이에요. 좋은 의도에서 나온 말이고, 저도 결국에는 PM(프로덕트 매니저)이 비즈니스에 가치 있는 성과를 만들어내는지로 자신의 성공을 측정해야 한다고 생각해요. 다만 그게 이번 분기에 특정 성과를 꼭 약속(commit)해야 한다거나, 우리가 그 성과를 어떻게 만들어야 할지 알 수도 모를 수도 있는 상황에서 특정 성과에 얽매여야 한다는 뜻은 아니에요.
text_zh: 我发现了一个现象，我觉得这算是很多公司都在搞的一个基本原则吧，就是总是强调要关注结果而不是产出。这个想法本身是好的，因为说到底，我觉得确实是这样，产品经理(PM)最终还是得靠能不能给业务带来有价值的结果来衡量自己成功不成功。但这不代表我们这个季度就一定要承诺达到某个具体结果，或者说我们应该承诺一个我们可能根本不知道怎么去推动的结果。
text_es: Una de las cosas que me di cuenta, y creo que es como un principio básico que está pasando en muchas empresas, es esta idea de siempre enfocarse en los resultados finales (outcomes) por encima de las entregas (outputs), y viene de un buen lugar, que al final del día, y creo que esto es cierto, un PM tiene que medir su éxito basándose en si logra generar resultados valiosos para el negocio. Pero eso no necesariamente significa que este trimestre tengamos que comprometernos a un resultado específico o que debamos comprometernos a un resultado específico que tal vez no sepamos ni cómo mover.
context: Lenny asks Ravi about his insights on goal-setting and best practices for aligning on goals. Ravi discusses problems with the common "outcomes over outputs" mantra, explaining that while ultimately PMs should drive business outcomes, it doesn't mean every quarter should have outcome-based commitments, especially when teams don't understand how to move those metrics.
vocabulary_highlights: comes from a good place, commit to a specific outcome, may or may not know how to move
topics: Product Management, Strategy & Planning, Decision Making

speaker: Ravi Mehta
text: And so one of the things that we said with stake that we put in the ground was the strategy doc wouldn't be complete without wireframes. This was the first time that we were doing that in the context of strategy. And the thing that we were really trying to solve for is the fact that oftentimes when you talk about strategy in words alone, everyone takes away a different interpretation of that strategy, whereas when you actually can show people wireframes of what the product will look like when that strategy is implemented, it creates much more alignment.
text_ko: 그래서 우리가 확고히 정해 둔 것 중 하나는 전략 문서(strategy doc)는 와이어프레임(wireframes) 없이 완성된 게 아니라고 한 거예요. 이걸 전략의 맥락에서 한 건 이번이 처음이었어요. 우리가 정말 해결하려고 했던 건 보통 전략을 말로만 얘기하면 사람마다 해석이 달라진다는 점이에요. 반면에 전략을 구현했을 때 제품이 어떻게 보일지 와이어프레임을 직접 보여주면 훨씬 더 합의(alignment)가 잘 돼요.
text_zh: 所以我们当时立了个规矩，就是说策略文档如果没有线框图(wireframes)那就不算完整。这是我们第一次在做策略的时候加入这个环节。我们其实就是想解决一个问题——你光用文字去讲策略，每个人理解的都不一样，但是如果你能拿出线框图，让大家看到这个策略落地后产品具体长什么样，大家就容易达成共识了。
text_es: Y entonces una de las cosas que dijimos, como una posición firme que tomamos, fue que el documento de estrategia no estaría completo sin los wireframes. Era la primera vez que hacíamos eso en el contexto de estrategia. Y lo que realmente estábamos tratando de resolver era el hecho de que muchas veces cuando hablas de estrategia solo con palabras, cada quien se lleva una interpretación diferente de esa estrategia, mientras que cuando realmente puedes mostrarle a la gente wireframes de cómo se va a ver el producto cuando esa estrategia se implemente, eso crea mucho más alineamiento.
context: Ravi shares an example from his time at Tripadvisor when they were developing a strategy for trip planning features. He explains how they established a rule requiring wireframes in strategy documents to create better alignment. This was an innovative approach at the time, designed to prevent different interpretations of written strategy by making the vision visually concrete.
vocabulary_highlights: stake that we put in the ground, takes away a different interpretation, creates much more alignment

speaker: Ray Cao
text: The number one thing is context, no control. That's the reason why we're always encouraging people to see themselves as a business owner. How do you actually solve the puzzle by connecting all the dots together? Just like how I see some of my friends, their kids playing Legos, if you don't really see the full picture, you won't be able to make the Lego as one thing at the end of the day.
text_ko: 가장 중요한 건 통제(control)가 아니라 맥락(context)이에요. 그래서 저희는 항상 사람들이 스스로를 사업주(business owner)로 생각하라고 권해요. 모든 점을 연결해서 퍼즐을 실제로 어떻게 푸는지 생각해보는 자세가 필요하다는 거죠. 제 친구들 아이들이 레고(LEGO) 가지고 노는 걸 보면 전체 그림을 보지 못하면 결국 하나의 완성품으로 못 만들더라고요.
text_zh: 最关键的是要看全局，而不是控制。所以我们总是鼓励大家把自己当成老板来思考。你怎么把所有的点串起来，解决这个难题？就像我看到朋友家的孩子玩乐高一样，如果你看不到完整的图案，最后肯定拼不出一个完整的东西来。
text_es: Lo más importante es el contexto, no el control. Por eso siempre estamos animando a la gente a que se vea como dueña de su propio negocio. ¿Cómo resuelves realmente el rompecabezas conectando todas las piezas? Es como cuando veo a los hijos de mis amigos jugando con Legos - si no tienes la imagen completa, al final del día no vas a poder armar el Lego como una sola cosa.
context: Lenny asks Ray about TikTok's core operating principles and cultural values. Ray explains TikTok's foundational principle of 'context, no control' - instead of giving employees narrow job descriptions and micromanaging them, TikTok provides comprehensive context about the business and encourages people to think like business owners who can see the full picture and connect different pieces together.
vocabulary_highlights: connecting all the dots together, full picture

speaker: Ray Cao
text: We always have this mentality we are a startup, we're a young company, we're always hungry for growth. And a very wacky way is like, 'How can I run my second half of my marathon faster than the first half?'
text_ko: 우리는 항상 스타트업(startup)이라는 마인드로 생각해요. 아직 젊은 회사고, 늘 성장에 목말라 있어요. 그리고 좀 엉뚱하게 들릴 수 있지만, '마라톤 후반을 전반보다 더 빨리 달릴 수 있을까?'라고 자주 스스로 물어봐요.
text_zh: 我们一直保持着创业公司的心态，我们是一家年轻的公司，对增长永远充满渴望。用一个很疯狂的比喻来说，就像是"我怎么能让马拉松的后半程跑得比前半程还快？"
text_es: Siempre tenemos esa mentalidad de que somos una startup, somos una empresa joven, siempre tenemos hambre de crecer. Y de una forma muy loca es como, "¿Cómo puedo correr la segunda mitad de mi maratón más rápido que la primera?"
context: Lenny continues asking about TikTok's cultural values and operating principles. Ray describes another core value called 'always day one' - maintaining a startup mentality despite TikTok's massive success. He uses a marathon metaphor to illustrate their philosophy of continuously accelerating rather than slowing down as they grow bigger.
vocabulary_highlights: hungry for growth, wacky way

speaker: Ray Cao
text: If we do have a ambition to go global, you have to do one more thing is actually take your step into global. Rather than having the machine do the heavy lifting, you have to really understand in local culture. Different market have totally different, I would say, culture and these market behaviors are actually coming out of this culture.
text_ko: 만약 우리가 글로벌 진출(go global)을 목표로 한다면, 한 가지 더 해야 할 일이 있어요. 실제로 글로벌 시장에 발을 들여놓아야 해요. 기계가 모든 힘든 일을 대신하게 하거나 자동화(automation)에만 맡기기보다는, 현지 문화(local culture)를 정말 잘 이해해야 해요. 각 시장은 완전히 다른 문화를 가지고 있고, 그 시장의 행동양식(market behaviors)은 바로 그 문화에서 나오거든요.
text_zh: 如果我们真的有全球化的野心，那就必须再做一件事，就是真正迈出全球化的步伐。不能光指望机器来搞定一切，你必须真正了解当地文化。不同市场的文化完全不一样，我觉得这些市场行为其实都是从文化中产生的。
text_es: Si realmente tenemos la ambición de expandirnos a nivel global, tienes que dar un paso más: realmente meterte de lleno en el mercado internacional. En lugar de dejar que la tecnología haga todo el trabajo pesado, tienes que entender a fondo la cultura local. Cada mercado es completamente diferente, yo diría que cada uno tiene su propia cultura, y los comportamientos del mercado en realidad surgen de esa cultura.
context: Lenny asks about TikTok's success across different global markets and whether their algorithm automatically figures out what works in each market. Ray explains that while technology helps, true global success requires understanding local cultures deeply. He emphasizes that you can't rely solely on algorithms - you need local talent and cultural understanding to fine-tune the machine learning systems.
vocabulary_highlights: do the heavy lifting, take your step into global

speaker: Ray Cao
text: The first mistake I made was... By that time we need to hire really fast. The goal is to hiring 100 people in a six month to support the go-to-market. Within six months I need to hire, I would say, 100 people and build everything. Then the first mistake I made just at the right point because we're trying to grow too fast and sometimes as a hiring manager I have to compromise the standard we're trying to hire.
text_ko: 제가 처음에 저지른 실수였어요. 그때는 정말 빨리 사람을 뽑아야 했거든요. 목표가 6개월 안에 시장 진입(go-to-market)을 지원할 100명을 채용하는 것이어서, 6개월 안에 100명을 뽑아 모든 것을 구축해야 했어요. 그런데 바로 그 중요한 시점에서 제가 실수를 했어요. 너무 빠르게 성장하려다 보니 채용 담당자(hiring manager)로서 채용 기준을 타협할 수밖에 없을 때가 있었거든요.
text_zh: 我犯的第一个错误是……那时候我们需要招人招得特别快。目标是六个月内招100个人来支持市场推广(go-to-market)。六个月内我得招，怎么说呢，100个人，然后把所有东西都搭建起来。然后我犯的第一个错误就是在这个节骨眼上，因为我们想发展得太快了，有时候作为招聘负责人，我不得不在招聘标准上妥协。
text_es: El primer error que cometí fue... Para ese momento necesitábamos contratar súper rápido. El objetivo era contratar 100 personas en seis meses para apoyar el lanzamiento al mercado (go-to-market). En seis meses necesitaba contratar, yo diría, 100 personas y armar todo. Entonces el primer error que cometí fue justo en ese punto porque estábamos tratando de crecer demasiado rápido y a veces como gerente de contratación tuve que bajar los estándares que queríamos mantener para las contrataciones.
context: Lenny asks Ray about failures in building TikTok's go-to-market organization and what went wrong initially. Ray shares that when he joined TikTok, there were only two people in go-to-market for US and Europe, and he needed to hire 100 people in six months. His biggest mistake was compromising hiring standards due to the pressure to scale quickly, which actually slowed things down rather than speeding them up.
vocabulary_highlights: compromise the standard, fall into the trap

speaker: Ray Cao
text: Join a start-up and join a rocket ship is a lifestyle. It is not necessarily a job you are working on from 9 to 5. So it is a different lifestyle and it is not built for everyone. So if you are not able to adjust your mentality towards some of the work that we are here to do and it's maybe not right fit for you.
text_ko: 스타트업(start-up)에 합류해 로켓십(rocket ship)에 올라타는 건 하나의 라이프스타일이에요. 꼭 9시부터 5시까지 출퇴근하는 직장처럼 일하는 건 아니에요. 그래서 다른 삶의 방식이고 누구에게나 맞는 건 아니에요. 우리가 하려는 일에 맞춰 마음가짐을 바꾸기 어렵다면, 아마 당신에게는 맞지 않을 거예요.
text_zh: 加入创业公司就像坐火箭一样，这是一种生活方式。不是说朝九晚五上个班就完事了。所以这是完全不同的生活方式，不是每个人都适合的。如果你没办法调整心态去适应我们要做的这些工作，那可能就不太合适你。
text_es: Meterte en una startup es como subirte a un cohete, es todo un estilo de vida. No es precisamente un trabajo de nueve a cinco. Es una forma de vida completamente diferente y no está hecha para todo el mundo. Entonces, si no puedes cambiar tu mentalidad hacia el tipo de trabajo que venimos a hacer aquí, puede que no sea lo tuyo.
context: Lenny asks Ray about what causes people to not succeed at TikTok and what the most common reasons are for people leaving or being let go. Ray explains that working at a fast-growing startup like TikTok requires a different lifestyle and mindset - it's not a traditional 9-to-5 job but rather demands more intense commitment and adaptability to rapid change.
vocabulary_highlights: rocket ship, right fit

speaker: Ray Cao
text: I would say leaning in is the first part. It's harder, but it is not that hard. As long as you try it, you'll feel that every single day is getting easier. Test and learn. A lot of times that people don't know how to really run ads on this platform. Google is very much search, like search fronts. They are really leading on the intent graph. And Meta is really on the people graph they're making. I mean TikTok is the content graph.
text_ko: 먼저, 적극적으로 참여하는 게 중요해요. 힘들긴 하지만 그렇게 어렵진 않아요. 시도만 하면 매일매일 조금씩 더 쉬워지는 걸 느낄 거예요. 테스트하고 배우는 거죠. 많은 사람들이 이 플랫폼에서 광고를 제대로 운영하는 방법을 잘 모르거든요. 구글은 검색 중심이에요. 검색 의도(intent graph)에서 정말 앞서가고 있고, 메타는 사람들 간의 관계를 기반으로 한 그래프를 만들고 있어요. 그리고 틱톡은 콘텐츠 그래프(content graph)죠.
