text_zh: 我觉得首先得全力投入进去。虽然有点难，但其实也没那么难。只要你去尝试，你会发现每天都比前一天容易一些。就是要不断测试和学习。很多时候大家其实不太懂怎么在这个平台上真正做好广告投放。Google主要还是搜索导向的，就是搜索前端那套，他们在意向图谱(intent graph)这块确实做得很领先。Meta更多是在做人群图谱(people graph)。我是说，TikTok就是内容图谱(content graph)。
text_es: Yo diría que meterse de lleno es lo primero. Es más difícil, pero tampoco es para tanto. Mientras lo intentes, vas a ver que cada día se vuelve más fácil. Prueba y aprende. Muchas veces la gente no sabe cómo hacer publicidad de verdad en esta plataforma. Google es muy de búsqueda, como frentes de búsqueda. Ellos dominan el gráfico de intención (intent graph). Y Meta está realmente en el gráfico de personas (people graph) que están armando. O sea, TikTok es el gráfico de contenido (content graph).
context: Lenny asks Ray for advice on how businesses can succeed as advertisers on TikTok's platform. Ray explains that the key is 'leaning in' - fully embracing TikTok's unique approach rather than applying strategies from other platforms. He clarifies that TikTok operates on a 'content graph' (algorithm-driven content distribution) which is fundamentally different from Google's intent-based search ads or Meta's friend-based social network advertising.
vocabulary_highlights: leaning in, intent graph, people graph, content graph

speaker: Ray Cao
text: I would say at least 10 different ad creatives will be ideal per week and the more the better. The more, the better. I would say at least 10 different ad creatives will be ideal per week.
text_ko: 일주일에 적어도 10개 정도의 다양한 광고 크리에이티브(ad creatives)가 이상적일 것 같아요. 그리고 많을수록 더 좋아요.
text_zh: 我觉得每周至少要有10个不同的广告素材(ad creatives)比较理想，当然是越多越好。越多越好。我觉得每周至少10个不同的广告素材是比较理想的。
text_es: Yo diría que al menos 10 creativos publicitarios diferentes por semana sería lo ideal, y mientras más, mejor. Mientras más, mejor. Yo diría que al menos 10 creativos publicitarios diferentes por semana sería lo ideal.
context: Lenny asks Ray for specific recommendations about how many ads a startup should test when exploring TikTok as an advertising channel. Ray advises that businesses should test at least 10 different creative advertisements per week to properly learn the platform and see what resonates with TikTok's audience. This high volume of testing is necessary because TikTok's content-based algorithm requires more experimentation to find what works.

speaker: Richard Rumelt
speaker_expertise: Growth Strategy, Leadership Development, Product Management
text: Don't call it strategy, call it an action agenda. It's huge numbers of people out there willing to sell you advice on mission and your vision and your values, all these things that have to be in place before you can have strategy. That's not true. Begin to try to identify the one or two key challenges that can actually be addressed and what are we going to do about it? What are the coherent actions we're going to do to take these on?
text_ko: 그걸 전략(strategy)이라고 부르지 말고 실행 어젠다(action agenda)라고 부르세요. 미션(mission), 비전(vision), 가치(values) 같은 걸 먼저 갖춰야 전략이 나온다고 조언을 팔려는 사람이 정말 많아요. 그런데 그건 사실이 아니에요. 실제로 해결할 수 있는 한두 가지 핵심 과제를 먼저 찾아보세요. 그리고 그 문제에 대해 우리가 뭘 할지, 그것들을 해결하기 위해 어떤 일관된 행동(coherent actions)을 취할지 구체적으로 정하세요.
text_zh: 别叫什么战略，就说行动计划得了。外面一大堆人想卖给你什么使命愿景价值观的咨询，说这些都得先搞定了才能做战略。胡扯！你就先找出一两个真正能解决的关键问题，然后想想我们具体怎么办？我们要采取哪些连贯的行动来解决这些问题？
text_es: No lo llames estrategia, dile agenda de acción. Hay muchísima gente por ahí dispuesta a venderte consejos sobre tu misión, tu visión, tus valores, todas esas cosas que supuestamente tienen que estar en su lugar antes de poder tener una estrategia. Eso no es cierto. Empieza por tratar de identificar uno o dos desafíos clave que realmente se puedan abordar y ¿qué vamos a hacer al respecto? ¿Cuáles son las acciones coherentes que vamos a tomar para enfrentarlos?
context: Lenny asks Richard to define strategy and explain the essential components of a good strategy. Richard explains that people often get confused by complex frameworks and should instead focus on practical action. He argues that many consultants overcomplicate strategy by insisting on elaborate mission and vision statements, when in reality you can start immediately by identifying your biggest challenges and deciding what concrete actions you'll take to address them.
vocabulary_highlights: coherent actions, huge numbers of people, in place

speaker: Richard Rumelt
speaker_expertise: Growth Strategy, Leadership Development, Product Management
text: Well, a strategy is a design for overcoming a high-stakes challenge. It's a mixture of policy and action designed to deal with a challenge. The challenge could have an upside. It could be, 'Oh geez, we were fooling around in the back 40 and we discovered oil, what we do?' Or it could be negative, could be that new innovation is driving us out of the market. But a challenge is the hardest strategy.
text_ko: 글쎄요, 전략(strategy)은 큰 이해관계가 걸린 과제를 극복하기 위한 설계예요. 정책(policy)과 행동(action)이 섞여서 그 과제를 다루려고 만든 거예요. 그 과제는 긍정적인 쪽일 수도 있어요. 예를 들면 "어머, 뒤뜰에서 이리저리 놀다가 기름을 발견했네, 이제 어떡하지?" 같은 상황이요. 반대로 부정적일 수도 있어요 — 새로운 혁신(innovation) 때문에 우리가 시장에서 밀려나는 경우처럼요. 어쨌든 그런 도전 과제가 전략에서 가장 어려운 부분이에요.
text_zh: 其实吧，战略就是为了应对高风险挑战而设计的一套方案。它把政策和行动混合在一起，专门用来解决挑战。这个挑战可能是好事儿，比如说"哎呀，我们在后院瞎折腾的时候发现了石油，现在该怎么办？"也可能是坏事儿，比如新的创新技术把我们挤出市场了。但不管怎样，有挑战的时候制定战略是最难的。
text_es: Bueno, una estrategia es básicamente un plan para superar un desafío de alto riesgo. Es una mezcla de políticas y acciones diseñadas para enfrentar un reto. El desafío puede tener su lado positivo. Puede ser algo como 'Oye, estábamos experimentando por ahí y descubrimos petróleo, ¿y ahora qué hacemos?' O puede ser negativo, como que una nueva innovación nos esté sacando del mercado. Pero enfrentar un desafío es lo más difícil de la estrategia.
context: Lenny asks Richard for the simplest way to understand what strategy actually is. Richard explains that strategy fundamentally exists to overcome important challenges, whether those challenges are opportunities (like discovering oil) or threats (like being displaced by innovation). He traces the word back to ancient Greek 'Strategoi' - elected leaders in Athens who dealt with pressing issues of their day, showing that strategy has always been about solving problems rather than abstract planning.
vocabulary_highlights: high-stakes challenge, fooling around in the back 40, driving us out of the market

speaker: Richard Rumelt
speaker_expertise: Growth Strategy, Leadership Development, Product Management
text: Bad strategy, the standard bad strategy for a corporation is a set of profit goals or performance goals. A set of goals. Goals are the engineering of how companies work to some extent. But abstract, high-level goals, they're not strategy, they're something else. They're ambitions. And ambitions are not a strategy.
text_ko: 나쁜 전략(bad strategy)이란, 기업에서 흔히 보이는 게 이익 목표(profit goals)나 성과 목표(performance goals)의 단순한 집합이에요. 그냥 목표들의 집합이에요. 목표들은 어느 정도 회사가 어떻게 작동하는지를 설계하는 역할을 해요. 하지만 추상적이고 상위 수준의 목표들은 전략이 아니고, 다른 거예요. 그건 야망(ambitions)이고, 야망은 전략이 아니에요.
text_zh: 烂策略，公司最典型的烂策略就是设一堆利润目标或者业绩指标。就是一堆目标嘛。目标在某种程度上算是公司运作的工程学吧。但是那些抽象的、高大上的目标，根本就不是战略，是别的东西。那叫野心、抱负。野心可不等于战略。
text_es: Una mala estrategia, la típica mala estrategia de las empresas son objetivos de ganancias o metas de rendimiento. Un montón de objetivos. Los objetivos son como la ingeniería de cómo funcionan las empresas hasta cierto punto. Pero esos objetivos abstractos de alto nivel, eso no es estrategia, es otra cosa. Son aspiraciones. Y las aspiraciones no son una estrategia.
context: Lenny asks Richard to identify signs of bad strategy. Richard explains that one of the most common mistakes organizations make is confusing goals with strategy. He points out that while goals like increasing profits or market share might be worthwhile ambitions, they don't constitute a strategy because they don't explain how these goals will be achieved or what specific challenges need to be overcome to reach them.
vocabulary_highlights: abstract, high-level goals

speaker: Richard Rumelt
speaker_expertise: Growth Strategy, Leadership Development, Product Management
text: Focus is... when I was nine years old, I was at summer camp and I had my parents sent me a magnifying glass and I was out there using the sun to try to cook a piece of wood. The magnifying glass focuses the sun's rays on the spot. Counselor came over and he said, 'Try this,' and he pulled out a black thread from his T-shirt, put it down. And I focused the sun's rays hard, popped out.
text_ko: 집중이란... 제가 아홉 살 때 여름 캠프에 있었는데, 부모님이 돋보기를 보내주셔서 밖에서 돋보기로 태양빛을 모아 나무 조각을 태워보려고 했어요. 돋보기가 태양 광선을 한 점에 모아주더라고요. 캠프 지도자가 다가와서 "이거 해봐" 하고는 티셔츠에서 검은 실을 꺼내 바닥에 놓았어요. 제가 태양빛을 세게 모으자 그 실이 순식간에 타버렸어요.
text_zh: 专注就是...我九岁那年在夏令营，我爸妈给我寄了个放大镜，我就在那儿用太阳光想把一块木头给烤熟。放大镜把阳光聚焦到一个点上。然后辅导员过来跟我说，"试试这个"，他从T恤上抽了根黑线头放下来。我把阳光使劲聚焦上去，啪的一下就断了。
text_es: El enfoque es... cuando tenía nueve años, estaba en un campamento de verano y mis papás me habían mandado una lupa. Ahí andaba usando el sol para tratar de quemar un pedazo de madera. La lupa concentra los rayos del sol en un punto. Se acercó un monitor y me dijo: "Prueba con esto", y sacó un hilo negro de su camiseta, lo puso ahí. Enfoqué bien fuerte los rayos del sol y ¡pum! se quemó al instante.
context: Lenny asks about the importance of focus in strategy, referencing a quote about how saying yes to too many things can turn good strategy into bad strategy. Richard uses a childhood story about using a magnifying glass to demonstrate the power of focus. He explains that just like the magnifying glass concentrates the sun's energy on a single point to create fire, effective strategy requires concentrating your resources and efforts on specific targets that can actually be affected.
vocabulary_highlights: focuses the sun's rays, popped out

speaker: Richard Rumelt
speaker_expertise: Growth Strategy, Leadership Development, Product Management
text: In a competitive situation, the fundamental aspect of power is something that's going to give you some sort of advantage. Usually it's in asymmetry of some kind. If two fighters are equally balanced or two horses are equally fetched or two armies are equally... And they meet in competition, it's 50/50. Who knows what will happen. For a strategy you need to exploit in asymmetry of some kind.
text_ko: 경쟁 상황(competitive situation)에서는 힘(power)의 근본적인 핵심이 결국 당신에게 어떤 식으로든 우위를 주는 것(advantage)이에요. 보통은 어떤 형태의 비대칭성(asymmetry)에서 나오죠. 두 파이터가 완전히 균형을 이루거나, 두 경주마의 기량이 같거나, 두 군대가 비슷하면 경쟁에서는 50대50이에요. 무슨 일이 일어날지 아무도 몰라요. 그래서 전략(strategy)을 세우려면 어떤 식으로든 그 비대칭성을 이용해야 해요.
text_zh: 在竞争环境下，权力的核心其实就是能给你带来某种优势的东西。通常都是某种不对称优势。如果两个拳手实力相当，或者两匹马势均力敌，或者两支军队旗鼓相当...当他们正面交锋时，胜负就是五五开，谁也说不准结果怎样。要想有策略，你就必须利用某种不对称优势。
text_es: En una situación competitiva, lo fundamental del poder es algo que te va a dar cierta ventaja. Normalmente viene de algún tipo de asimetría. Si dos luchadores están completamente equilibrados o dos caballos están igual de preparados o dos ejércitos están parejos... Y se enfrentan en competencia, es 50/50. Quién sabe qué va a pasar. Para tener una estrategia necesitas explotar algún tipo de asimetría.
context: Lenny asks Richard to explain the concept of 'power' in strategy and why it's important. Richard explains that power comes from asymmetries - differences that give you an advantage over competitors. He uses the analogy of equally matched fighters or armies to show that without some form of asymmetry or advantage, any competitive situation becomes a coin flip. The key to strategic success is identifying and exploiting these asymmetries.
vocabulary_highlights: exploit in asymmetry, equally fetched

speaker: Richard Rumelt
speaker_expertise: Growth Strategy, Leadership Development, Product Management
text: I start, as I said earlier, with the symmetries. In what way is my company different than other companies? In what way is my team different? What do we know that other people don't know? What do we possess that other people don't possess? So there has to be some asymmetry to create competitive power, there has to be something different.
text_ko: 제가 앞서 말했듯이, 저는 대칭성(symmetries)부터 살펴봐요. 제 회사는 다른 회사들과 어떤 점에서 다른가요? 제 팀은 어떻게 다른가요? 다른 사람들이 모르는 것을 우리는 무엇을 알고 있나요? 다른 사람들이 갖고 있지 않은 것을 우리는 무엇을 가지고 있나요? 경쟁력(competitive power)을 만들려면 비대칭성(asymmetry)이 있어야 하고, 뭔가 달라야 해요.
text_zh: 就像我刚才说的，我首先会看不对称性。我们公司和别人有什么不一样的地方？我们团队有什么独特之处？我们知道什么别人不知道的东西？我们有什么别人没有的？要想有竞争力，就必须得有些不对称的地方，必须得有点与众不同的东西。
text_es: Como mencioné antes, empiezo por las simetrías. ¿En qué se diferencia mi empresa de las demás? ¿En qué es diferente mi equipo? ¿Qué sabemos nosotros que otros no saben? ¿Qué tenemos que otros no tienen? Tiene que haber alguna asimetría para crear poder competitivo, tiene que haber algo que nos distinga.
context: Lenny asks for practical advice on how people can figure out where their competitive power might lie. Richard provides a framework for identifying sources of power by systematically examining asymmetries. He suggests asking what knowledge, capabilities, or resources your organization possesses that competitors don't have equal access to. This could include specialized knowledge, unique relationships, proprietary technology, or other distinctive assets.

speaker: Richard Rumelt
speaker_expertise: Growth Strategy, Leadership Development, Product Management
text: Well, you're dealing with a lot of uncertainty When you're a founder in a startup, you're making a bet. You're making a bet like an oil well [inaudible] say, 'I bet there's oil under this ground. We're going to drill, we're going to find it.' There's a certain amount of bet that's going on, and you should be clear about the nature of the bet.
text_ko: 음, 불확실성이 정말 많아요. 창업자(founder)로서 스타트업(startup)을 할 때는 일종의 베팅(bet)을 하는 거예요. 마치 “이 땅 아래에 기름이 있을 거야, 우리가 시추해서 찾아낼 거야”라고 말하면서 유정(oil well)을 파는 것과 같아요. 어느 정도의 베팅이 진행되는 상황이고, 그 베팅의 성격이 무엇인지 분명히 해둬야 해요.
text_zh: 嗯，作为创业者你要面对很多不确定性。创业就像是在下注，就像开采石油一样，你得说"我赌这地底下有油，咱们钻下去肯定能找到"。创业本身就带有赌博的性质，你得清楚自己到底在赌什么。
text_es: Bueno, te enfrentas a mucha incertidumbre. Cuando eres fundador de una startup, estás apostando. Estás haciendo una apuesta como un pozo petrolero... digamos, "Apuesto a que hay petróleo bajo este suelo. Vamos a perforar y lo vamos a encontrar." Hay cierto nivel de apuesta en juego, y tienes que tener claro cuál es la naturaleza de esa apuesta.
context: Lenny asks what strategy should look like for startup founders who are pre-product-market fit and dealing with high uncertainty. Richard explains that startups are fundamentally making bets about markets, customers, and solutions. Like oil prospectors betting on where to drill, founders are betting on specific customer-product combinations. He emphasizes the importance of being explicit about what assumptions you're betting on, since reality will reveal whether these bets are correct through market feedback.
vocabulary_highlights: making a bet, nature of the bet

speaker: Robby Stein
speaker_expertise: AI/ML Products, User Experience, Growth Strategy
text: Google's mission around have any information be universally accessible, this very enduring, very motivating thing, and it feels like with the AI moment, we can actually achieve that more than ever before. What I'm feeling now is just an incredible sense of focus and urgency. Things have hit a tipping point where these models are now truly able to deliver for consumers.
text_ko: 구글의 미션은 모든 정보가 누구나 접근할 수 있게 만드는 거예요. 이건 정말 지속적이고 동기 부여가 되는 목표인데, 지금 AI의 시대에 우리가 그 목표를 그 어느 때보다 더 이룰 수 있을 것 같아요. 지금 느끼는 건 엄청난 집중력과 긴박감이에요. 이제 이 모델들이 소비자들에게 진짜로 도움이 될 수 있는 전환점에 도달한 것 같아요.
text_zh: 谷歌的使命就是让所有信息都能被全世界的人获取到，这个目标特别持久，也特别激励人，现在感觉有了AI这个机会，我们比以前任何时候都更有可能实现这个目标。我现在的感受就是特别专注，特别紧迫。现在已经到了一个临界点，这些模型(models)真的能够为消费者提供价值了。
text_es: La misión de Google de que cualquier información sea accesible para todos, es algo muy duradero y motivador, y con este momento de la IA, siento que realmente podemos lograrlo más que nunca. Lo que estoy sintiendo ahora es una sensación increíble de enfoque y urgencia. Las cosas han llegado a un punto de inflexión (tipping point) donde estos modelos ya pueden verdaderamente cumplir para los consumidores.
context: Lenny asks Robby about the recent success of Google Gemini hitting number one in the App Store and whether something has changed internally at Google. Robby explains that Google's core mission of making information universally accessible feels more achievable than ever with AI. He emphasizes that the focus and urgency at Google has intensified because AI models have reached a tipping point where they can truly deliver value for consumers.
vocabulary_highlights: universally accessible, very enduring, hit a tipping point, deliver for consumers
topics: Product Management, Strategy & Planning, Leadership & Management

speaker: Robby Stein
speaker_expertise: AI/ML Products, User Experience, Growth Strategy
text: The core Google search isn't really changing, in my opinion. We're not seeing that people come to search for just ridiculously wide set of things. They want a specific phone number, they want a price for something, they want to get directions. I think the vastness of that is underappreciated by many people. AI is expansionary.
text_ko: 제 생각엔 구글 검색의 핵심은 사실 크게 바뀌지 않았어요. 사람들이 검색하러 와서 정말 무작정 광범위한 것들을 찾는 건 아니에요. 대부분은 특정 전화번호를 찾거나, 제품의 가격을 확인하거나, 길 안내를 받으러 와요. 그런 수요의 방대함을 많은 사람이 과소평가하고 있는 것 같아요. 인공지능(AI)은 확장적이에요 — 기능과 사용 사례를 계속 넓혀줘요.
text_zh: 在我看来，谷歌搜索的核心其实没怎么变。我们发现用户并不是来搜索什么五花八门的东西。他们就是想要个具体的电话号码，想知道某样东西多少钱，想查个路线什么的。我觉得很多人都小看了这种需求的广泛性。AI是有扩张性的。
text_es: En mi opinión, la búsqueda principal de Google realmente no está cambiando. No estamos viendo que la gente venga a buscar cosas súper variadas o disparatadas. Quieren un número de teléfono específico, quieren saber el precio de algo, quieren conseguir direcciones. Creo que muchas personas no valoran lo enorme que es eso. La IA es expansiva.
context: Lenny asks about the impact of ChatGPT and other AI chatbots on Google search, wondering if people still want to go through search results instead of getting direct answers. Robby explains that core search behavior hasn't changed - people still come to Google for a ridiculously wide variety of specific needs. He argues that AI is actually expansionary, meaning it creates more opportunities for search rather than replacing it.
vocabulary_highlights: ridiculously wide set, vastness of that, underappreciated, expansionary

speaker: Robby Stein
speaker_expertise: AI/ML Products, User Experience, Growth Strategy
text: You need to be the physical manifestation of two pieces of things. One is just relentlessness, just complete effort that is always exerted in a direction of positive productivity. And then the second is make things better. You have to always make things better. You're never content.
text_ko: 직접 보여줘야 하는 건 두 가지예요. 하나는 끈질긴 집념(relentlessness)으로, 언제나 생산적인 방향으로 온힘을 다하는 태도예요. 두 번째는 늘 더 좋게 만드는 자세예요. 항상 개선하려고 하고 결코 만족하면 안 돼요.
text_zh: 你得具备两个特质。第一个就是要有韧劲儿，就是那种不达目的不罢休的劲头，永远朝着积极的方向全力以赴。第二个就是要不断改进优化。你必须时刻想着怎么把事情做得更好，永远不能满足于现状。
text_es: Tienes que ser la manifestación física de dos cosas. Una es ser implacable, poner el cien por ciento de tu esfuerzo siempre hacia algo productivo y positivo. Y la segunda es mejorar las cosas constantemente. Siempre tienes que estar mejorando todo. Nunca puedes conformarte con lo que tienes.
context: Lenny asks Robby about his philosophy of 'embodying relentless improvement' and what that means for building successful products. Robby explains that this concept has two key components: relentlessness (complete effort always directed toward positive productivity) and continuously making things better while never being content with the current state. This philosophy drives the constant improvement needed for breakthrough products.
vocabulary_highlights: physical manifestation, complete effort, exerted in a direction, positive productivity

speaker: Robby Stein
speaker_expertise: AI/ML Products, User Experience, Growth Strategy
text: Not every great thing is going to be invented by you. Facebook probably created the modern feed, but there's a feed for every single product. At the end of the day, you're just robbing your user base of the opportunity to have a better product.
text_ko: 모든 멋진 걸 여러분이 다 발명해야 하는 건 아니에요. 페이스북이 현대적 피드(feed)를 만든 건 맞지만, 사실 거의 모든 제품(product)에 피드가 있어요. 결국엔 여러분이 사용자 기반(user base)에게 더 나은 제품(product)을 가질 기회를 빼앗고 있는 거예요.
text_zh: 不是所有好东西都得你自己发明出来。Facebook可能创造了现代信息流(feed)的概念，但现在每个产品都有信息流(feed)功能。说到底，你这样做就是让用户失去了用更好产品的机会，这不是坑自己的用户吗？
text_es: No todo lo genial lo vas a inventar tú. Facebook probablemente creó el feed moderno, pero ahora hay un feed para cada producto. Al final del día, solo le estás quitando a tus usuarios la oportunidad de tener un mejor producto.
context: Lenny brings up the controversial launch of Instagram Stories, which was criticized for copying Snapchat's format. Robby defends the decision by explaining that not every innovation needs to be original - formats like feeds become universal primitives across products. He argues that refusing to adopt better formats would be robbing users of improved experiences, emphasizing that the focus should be on serving users rather than claiming originality.
vocabulary_highlights: robbing your user base

speaker: Robby Stein
speaker_expertise: AI/ML Products, User Experience, Growth Strategy
text: I think the most recent one, and this is true, something even within the last week or two, is that it's so obvious how human-like the interface is becoming with how you can communicate and steer AI. I think it used to be even just months back that you had to do a lot of work to get the AI to do the thing you're trying to get it to do, right?
text_ko: 최근에 가장 인상적이었던 건, 사실 지난 일주일이나 이주일 사이의 일인데, AI(AI)와 소통하고 원하는 방향으로 이끌 수 있게 된 인터페이스(interface)가 얼마나 인간적으로 변해 가는지가 너무 분명해졌다는 점이에요. 몇 달 전만 해도 원하는 걸 AI에게 하려면 훨씬 더 많은 노력을 기울여야 했던 것 같아요, 그렇죠?
text_zh: 我觉得最近的一个变化，这是真的，就在上周或者前两周吧，就是AI的交互界面变得越来越像人了，你跟它沟通、引导它的方式特别自然。我记得就几个月前，你还得费老大劲儿才能让AI做你想要它做的事情，对吧？
text_es: Mira, lo más reciente, y esto es cierto, algo que pasó literalmente la semana pasada o hace dos semanas, es que se nota muchísimo lo parecido a una conversación humana que se está volviendo la forma de comunicarte y dirigir la IA. Creo que hasta hace unos meses tenías que hacer un montón de trabajo para lograr que la IA hiciera lo que realmente querías que hiciera, ¿no?
context: Lenny asks Robby what he's learned about building AI products that might surprise people. Robby shares that one of the most surprising recent developments is how human-like AI interfaces have become. He explains that just months ago, users had to do extensive prompt engineering and use specific techniques to get AI to perform tasks, but now the interaction is becoming much more natural and conversational.
vocabulary_highlights: steer AI, do a lot of work

speaker: Robby Stein
speaker_expertise: AI/ML Products, User Experience, Growth Strategy
text: I think that you need to be the physical manifestation of two pieces of things. One is just relentlessness, just complete effort, but is always exerted in a direction of positive productivity. And then the second is make things better. You have to always make things better, you're never content.
text_ko: 제가 보기에는 두 가지를 몸소 보여줘야 해요. 하나는 끈질김(relentlessness), 전력을 다하는 태도인데 그 노력이 항상 생산적이고 긍정적인 방향(positive productivity)으로 향해야 해요. 두 번째는 늘 더 나아지게 만들기(make things better)예요. 항상 개선하려고 해야 하고, 결코 현 상태에 만족하면 안 돼요.
text_zh: 我觉得你需要体现两个方面。第一个就是要有那种不服输的劲头，全力以赴去干，但一定要往正确的方向使劲，要有产出。第二个就是要不断改进，永远想着怎么把事情做得更好，不能满足于现状。
text_es: Creo que tienes que ser la manifestación física de dos cosas. Una es ser implacable, dar todo de ti, pero siempre enfocando esa energía hacia algo productivo y positivo. Y la segunda es mejorar las cosas constantemente. Siempre tienes que estar mejorando las cosas, nunca conformarte con lo que tienes.
context: Lenny asks about Robby's core philosophy for building successful products. Robby explains his concept of 'embodying relentless improvement' which came from a personal story where his wife described him as 'dissatisfied' - meaning he's driven by a desire to make the world better. He breaks this philosophy into two components: relentless effort in a productive direction, and never being content with the current state of things.
vocabulary_highlights: physical manifestation, exerted in a direction, positive productivity
topics: Product Management, Leadership & Management, Coaching & Development

speaker: Robby Stein
speaker_expertise: AI/ML Products, User Experience, Growth Strategy
text: I think there's typically three things I think about. If I were to write a book about how to build great products, there'd be three chapters. The first is deeply understand people, and I think we talked about this a little bit with the jobs to be done point and Clayton Christensen's book, which I loved around Competing Against Luck.
text_ko: 제가 보통 생각하는 건 세 가지예요. 훌륭한 제품을 만드는 법에 대해 책을 쓴다면 장도 세 개로 나눌 것 같고요. 첫째는 사람을 깊이 이해하는 거예요. 이건 우리가 '해야 할 일(jobs to be done)' 관점에서 조금 얘기했던 부분이고, 저는 클레이튼 크리스텐슨의 책 'Competing Against Luck'을 정말 좋아해요.
text_zh: 我觉得通常有三个方面需要考虑。如果让我写一本关于如何打造优秀产品的书，我会分三个章节。第一章就是深度理解用户需求，这个我们刚才聊"待完成任务"(jobs to be done)理论时也提到了，还有克莱顿·克里斯坦森那本《与运气竞争》(Competing Against Luck)，我特别喜欢那本书。
text_es: Yo creo que típicamente hay tres cosas en las que pienso. Si fuera a escribir un libro sobre cómo crear productos increíbles, tendría tres capítulos. El primero es entender profundamente a las personas, y creo que ya tocamos esto un poco cuando hablamos del tema de "trabajos por hacer" (jobs to be done) y el libro de Clayton Christensen, que me encantó, "Competing Against Luck".
context: Lenny asks Robby to share his core product principles that have helped him build successful products across Instagram and Google. Robby outlines his framework for a hypothetical three-chapter book on building great products, starting with the first principle of deeply understanding people. He references Clayton Christensen's 'jobs to be done' framework from 'Competing Against Luck' as a key methodology for understanding why people hire products to solve their problems.
topics: Product Management, Strategy & Planning, Learning & Growth

speaker: Roger Martin
text: What's taught now in business schools generally sucks. People aren't prepared educationally, and they sure don't get prepared for it in companies. It's intellectually challenging and it's emotionally intimidating.
text_ko: 지금 경영대학원(business schools)에서 가르치는 건 대체로 형편없어요. 사람들은 교육적으로 준비가 안 돼 있고, 회사에서도 전혀 준비시켜 주지 않아요. 그건 지적으로는 도전적이고 정서적으로는 위압적이에요.
text_zh: 现在商学院教的那些东西基本上都不怎么样。学生在学校里没学到什么真本事，进了公司也得不到什么像样的培训。这活儿既烧脑又让人压力山大。
text_es: Lo que enseñan ahora en las escuelas de negocios es bastante malo. La gente no viene preparada desde la educación, y desde luego tampoco los preparan en las empresas. Es un desafío intelectual enorme y emocionalmente te puede intimidar muchísimo.
context: Lenny asks Roger why so many people are bad at strategy. Roger explains that there are multiple reasons why strategy is difficult for most people. He identifies that business schools have moved away from teaching practical strategy and instead focus on theoretical approaches that don't work in the real world. Companies also don't provide good strategic training, leaving people unprepared for the intellectual and emotional challenges that strategy work requires.
vocabulary_highlights: generally sucks, intellectually challenging, emotionally intimidating

speaker: Roger Martin
text: Strategy is an integrated set of choices that compels desired customer action. So, the way I think about it is, there's a whole bunch of things a company controls, how many factories to build, how much R&D to do, in what areas, and how much advertising to do, how many people to hire, what to pay them, blah, blah, blah... Those are all the things under our control.
text_ko: 전략(strategy)은 원하는 고객 행동을 이끌어내는 선택들의 통합된 집합이에요. 제가 보는 관점은, 회사가 통제할 수 있는 것들이 아주 많다는 거예요 — 공장을 몇 개 지을지, 연구개발(R&D)을 얼마나 할지 어느 분야에 투자할지, 광고(advertising)를 얼마나 할지, 몇 명을 채용할지, 임금을 얼마로 책정할지, 뭐 이런저런… 이 모든 게 우리가 통제할 수 있는 것들이에요.
text_zh: 战略就是一套完整的选择组合，能够推动客户按我们希望的方式行动。我是这么理解的，公司能控制的东西有一大堆，比如建多少工厂，研发投入多少钱、投在哪些领域，广告预算怎么分配，招多少人，给多少薪水，等等等等...这些都是我们能掌控的。
text_es: La estrategia es un conjunto integrado de decisiones que impulsa a los clientes a hacer lo que queremos. O sea, como yo lo veo, hay un montón de cosas que la empresa puede controlar: cuántas plantas construir, cuánto invertir en I+D (R&D), en qué áreas, cuánta publicidad hacer, a cuánta gente contratar, cuánto pagarles, y así sucesivamente... Todas esas son cosas que están bajo nuestro control.
context: Lenny asks Roger to define what strategy actually is. Roger provides his core definition of strategy and explains the fundamental challenge - companies can control their internal decisions like factories, R&D spending, and hiring, but they cannot control what customers ultimately choose to do. Strategy is therefore about making the right internal choices to influence customer behavior in your favor.
vocabulary_highlights: integrated set of choices, compels desired customer action, blah, blah, blah

speaker: Roger Martin
text: You have to be either differentiated or low cost, there's no way to protect yourself if you're not one of those two. It's literally like having a bully who can just shove you, and you take one step back, then they shove you, and you take another step back, and they shove you, and you take another step back.
text_ko: 차별화(differentiated)되거나 저비용(low cost)이어야 해요. 그 둘 중 하나가 아니면 자신을 보호할 방법이 전혀 없어요. 말 그대로 괴롭히는 상대가 계속 밀어붙이는 것과 같아요. 한 번 밀면 한 발 물러서고, 또 밀면 또 한 발 물러서고, 그렇게 계속 밀려요.
text_zh: 你必须要么有差异化，要么成本够低，如果这两样你都不占，那就没法保护自己。这就像遇到一个恶霸，他推你一下，你就往后退一步，他再推你，你又退一步，他接着推，你还是只能继续往后退。
text_es: Tienes que ser diferente o ser el más barato, no hay otra forma de protegerte si no eres una de estas dos cosas. Es literalmente como tener un matón que te empuja, y tú das un paso atrás, luego te empuja otra vez, y das otro paso atrás, y te vuelve a empujar, y sigues retrocediendo.
context: Lenny asks about the two routes to winning that Roger describes - being the lowest cost option or being differentiated. Roger emphasizes that these are the only two viable competitive positions, referencing Michael Porter's foundational strategy work. He uses a vivid analogy to explain what happens to companies that get stuck in the middle - they become vulnerable to competitors who can push them around at will because they have no defensible position.
vocabulary_highlights: no way to protect yourself, literally like having a bully

speaker: Roger Martin
text: You'll know you're playing to play if you're not aiming to, and accomplishing, having either an offer where Lenny walks into the store, whatever kind of store it is, and says to the person in the store, I want that brand. An example, Lego, one of the companies I've worked with for a long time, great company.
text_ko: 당신이 플레이 투 플레이(playing to play)를 하고 있는지 아는 방법은, Lenny가 아무 가게에 들어가서 점원한테 "저 브랜드 갖고 싶어요"라고 말하게 만드는 오퍼(offer)를 목표로 삼지도 않고, 또 실제로 만들어내지도 못하고 있을 때예요. 예로 제가 오랫동안 함께 일해온 훌륭한 회사인 레고(Lego)가 있어요.
text_zh: 你就知道自己是在瞎折腾，如果你做不到这一点的话——就是让任何一个顾客，比如说Lenny，走进店里，不管是什么店，然后跟店员说"我就要那个牌子的"。举个例子，乐高，我合作了很久的一家公司，非常棒的企业。
text_es: Sabrás que estás jugando por jugar si no te estás enfocando en lograr que tu oferta sea tan fuerte que Lenny entre a la tienda, del tipo que sea, y le diga al vendedor "quiero esa marca". Un ejemplo perfecto es Lego, una de las empresas con las que he trabajado por mucho tiempo, excelente compañía.
context: Lenny asks how to recognize if you're just "playing to play" rather than "playing to win" in your strategy. Roger explains that customers provide the clearest signal - if customers specifically request your brand by name rather than seeing you as interchangeable with competitors, you're truly winning. He uses Lego as an example of a brand that has achieved this level of customer preference and loyalty.
vocabulary_highlights: playing to play, walks into the store

speaker: Roger Martin
text: I have never met this mythical beast called a great natural strategist. Great strategists have all one thing in common, they just practice. And anybody, there's no such thing as a person who is willing to practice strategy, who will end up saying, I'm operational, I don't do strategy well.
text_ko: 저는 '타고난 전략가(natural strategist)'라는 전설 같은 존재를 한 번도 만나본 적이 없어요. 위대한 전략가들에게는 공통점이 하나 있는데, 그냥 연습을 한다는 거예요. 그리고 누구든 전략(strategy)을 기꺼이 연습하는 사람이라면 결국 '나는 오퍼레이션(operational)만 해요, 전략은 잘 못해요'라고 말하게 되는 일은 없어요.
text_zh: 我从来没见过什么天生的战略大师这种神话般的存在。真正厉害的战略家都有一个共同点，就是不断练习。任何人，只要愿意花时间练战略思维，绝对不会最后还说"我只会做执行，战略我搞不好"。
text_es: Nunca me he topado con esa criatura mítica que llaman "el gran estratega nato". Los grandes estrategas tienen una cosa en común: simplemente practican. Y cualquier persona, no existe alguien que esté dispuesto a practicar estrategia que termine diciendo "soy operativo, no se me da bien la estrategia".
context: As Roger wraps up the conversation, Lenny asks if there's any final advice he'd like to share. Roger addresses a common misconception that some people are just naturally gifted at strategy while others aren't. He argues that strategic thinking is a learned skill that improves with practice, not an innate talent. He encourages listeners to start practicing strategic thinking rather than waiting or assuming they're not cut out for it.
vocabulary_highlights: mythical beast, natural strategist, just practice
topics: Strategy & Planning, Learning & Growth, Career Development

speaker: Roger Martin
text: I just think of it as a problem solving tool. And what problem should you attempt to solve? You should attempt to solve something where your current outcomes that you're getting are lower than the outcomes you wish you were getting. That's what I call a gap.
text_ko: 저는 그걸 그냥 문제 해결 도구(problem solving tool)로 생각해요. 어떤 문제를 풀어야 하냐고요? 바로 지금 얻고 있는 결과가 원하던 성과만큼 나오지 않을 때 그 문제를 풀어야 해요. 저는 그걸 격차(gap)라고 불러요.
text_zh: 我觉得这就是个解决问题的工具嘛。那应该解决什么问题呢？你应该去解决那种现状跟你期望的结果之间有差距的问题。我把这个叫做缺口(gap)。
text_es: Yo simplemente lo veo como una herramienta para resolver problemas. ¿Y qué problema deberías intentar resolver? Deberías enfocarte en algo donde los resultados que estás obteniendo ahora están por debajo de los resultados que te gustaría tener. A eso yo le llamo una brecha (gap).
context: Lenny asks Roger for a tactical approach to help people who feel overwhelmed by strategy work. Roger introduces his concept of "betterment over perfection" as a practical starting point. Instead of trying to solve everything at once, he recommends identifying the most painful gap between current performance and desired outcomes, then using strategic thinking to close that specific gap before moving to the next one.
vocabulary_highlights: problem solving tool, That's what I call a gap
topics: Strategy & Planning, Decision Making, Learning & Growth

speaker: Ronny Kohavi
text: I'm very clear that I'm a big fan of test everything, which is any code change that you make, any feature that you introduce has to be in some experiment. Because again, I've observed this sort of surprising result that even small bug fixes, even small changes can sometimes have surprising, unexpected impact.
text_ko: 저는 '모든 것을 테스트하기(test everything)' 방식을 아주 강하게 지지해요. 즉, 코드 변경이나 새로 도입하는 기능은 모두 어떤 형태로든 실험(experiment)을 통해 검증돼야 해요. 다시 말하지만, 제가 경험해 보니 작은 버그 수정이나 사소한 변경조차 때로는 예상치 못한 영향을 줄 수 있더라고요.
text_zh: 我的态度很明确，我是"全面测试"的忠实拥护者，也就是说你做的任何代码修改、引入的任何功能都必须放到实验(experiment)里去验证。因为我发现了一个很意外的现象，就是哪怕是修个小bug、做个小改动，有时候都会产生让人意想不到的影响。
text_es: Tengo muy claro que soy súper fan de testear todo, o sea, cualquier cambio de código que hagas, cualquier funcionalidad nueva que introduzcas tiene que estar en algún experimento. Porque otra vez, he visto este resultado medio sorprendente de que hasta las correcciones de bugs más pequeñas, hasta los cambios más mínimos a veces pueden tener un impacto sorprendente e inesperado.
context: Lenny asks whether you can be too experiment-driven, mentioning concerns that experimentation leads only to micro-optimizations and prevents big innovations. Ronny responds by advocating for testing everything through experiments, explaining that even seemingly minor changes like small bug fixes can have unexpected impacts on user behavior and business metrics.
vocabulary_highlights: big fan of, sort of surprising result

speaker: Ronny Kohavi
text: You have to allocate sometimes to these high risk, high reward ideas. We're going to try something that's most likely to fail. But if it does win, it's going to be a home run. And you have to be ready to understand and agree that most will fail.
text_ko: 가끔은 하이 리스크 하이 리턴(high risk, high reward)인 아이디어에 자원을 배분해야 해요. 실패할 가능성이 가장 높은 걸 시도해 보려고 해요. 하지만 성공하면 홈런(home run)이 될 거예요. 그리고 대부분은 실패할 거라는 걸 이해하고 받아들일 준비가 돼 있어야 해요.
text_zh: 有时候你得在这些高风险高回报的想法上投点钱。我们要尝试一些很可能失败的东西，但如果成功了，那就是全垒打(home run)。你必须做好心理准备，接受大部分都会失败这个现实。
text_es: A veces tienes que apostar por esas ideas de alto riesgo y alta recompensa. Vamos a intentar algo que probablemente va a fracasar. Pero si funciona, va a ser un pelotazo. Y tienes que estar preparado para entender y aceptar que la mayoría van a fallar.
context: Continuing his response about experimentation strategy, Ronny explains that teams need a portfolio approach to experiments. While some experiments should focus on incremental improvements with higher success rates, teams must also dedicate resources to ambitious, risky ideas that have low probability of success but could deliver breakthrough results if they work.
vocabulary_highlights: high risk, high reward, home run
topics: Product Management, Strategy & Planning, Decision Making

speaker: Ronny Kohavi
text: And it's amazing how many times I've seen people come up with new designs or a radical new idea. And they believe in it, and that's okay. I'm just cautioning them all the time to say, 'If you go for something big, try it out, but be ready to fail 80% of the time.'
text_ko: 사람들이 새로운 디자인이나 파격적인 아이디어를 떠올리는 걸 얼마나 자주 보는지 정말 놀라워요. 그리고 그걸 믿는 것도 괜찮아요. 다만 저는 항상 이렇게 얘기해요: "큰 도전을 하려면 시도는 해보되, 80%는 실패할 준비를 하세요."
text_zh: 我见过太多人想出新设计或者很颠覆性的想法，他们特别相信自己的点子，这没问题。但我总是提醒他们：如果你想搞个大的，可以试试看，但要做好失败的准备——十有八九都会失败的。
text_es: Y es increíble cuántas veces he visto a gente que se le ocurren diseños nuevos o una idea súper innovadora. Y se la creen a muerte, y está bien. Pero siempre les estoy advirtiendo: 'Si van a por algo grande, pruébenlo, pero prepárense para fallar el 80% de las veces.'
context: Ronny continues discussing the balance between incremental and revolutionary experiments. He acknowledges that it's natural for people to believe strongly in their big ideas, but emphasizes the importance of setting realistic expectations about failure rates, especially for ambitious experiments that attempt major changes to user experiences.
vocabulary_highlights: radical new idea, cautioning them, go for something big
topics: Product Management, Leadership & Management, Decision Making

speaker: Ronny Kohavi
text: Of these experiments, 92% failed to improve the metric that we were trying to move. So only 8% of our ideas actually were successful at moving the key metrics.
text_ko: 이 실험들(experiments) 중 92%는 우리가 움직이려고 했던 지표(metric)를 개선하지 못했어요. 그래서 결국 우리 아이디어(ideas) 중 실제로 핵심 지표(key metrics)를 움직인 건 단 8%뿐이었어요.
text_zh: 这些实验里面，92%都没能把我们想要提升的指标搞上去。所以我们的想法中，真正能推动关键指标的其实只有8%。
text_es: De todos estos experimentos, el 92% no logró mejorar la métrica que queríamos impactar. O sea que solo el 8% de nuestras ideas realmente funcionaron para mover las métricas clave.
context: Ronny is explaining the reality of experiment success rates at Airbnb's search team, where he ran approximately 250 experiments during his tenure. Despite these experiments ultimately contributing to a 6% overall improvement in revenue, the vast majority of individual experiment ideas failed to move their target metrics, illustrating the humble reality of how difficult it is to predict what will actually work.
vocabulary_highlights: move the metric, move the key metrics

speaker: Ronny Kohavi
text: I think one of the mistakes that some company makes is they launch a lot of experiments and never go back and summarize the learnings. So I've actually put a lot of effort in this idea of institutional learning, of doing the quarterly meeting of the most surprising experiments.
text_ko: 제가 보기엔 어떤 회사들이 하는 실수 중 하나가 실험은 많이 해두고 정작 배운 점을 되돌아보거나 정리하지 않는 거예요. 그래서 저는 제도화된 학습(institutional learning)에 많은 공을 들였고, 가장 놀라웠던 실험들을 모아 분기별 회의(quarterly meeting)를 여는 일을 실제로 하고 있어요.
text_zh: 我觉得有些公司犯的一个错误就是，做了一大堆实验但从来不回头总结学到了什么。所以我其实在制度化学习这块下了很大功夫，每个季度都开会专门讲那些最让人意外的实验结果。
text_es: Creo que uno de los errores que cometen algunas empresas es que lanzan un montón de experimentos y nunca regresan a hacer un resumen de lo que aprendieron. Así que yo le he puesto mucho empeño a esta idea del aprendizaje institucional, de hacer esa junta trimestral de los experimentos más sorprendentes.
context: Lenny suggests using AI to create product roadmaps from experiment patterns, which leads Ronny to discuss the importance of institutional memory in experimentation. He explains that many companies fail to capture and share learnings from their experiments, missing opportunities to build organizational knowledge that could inform future decisions and prevent repeating mistakes.
vocabulary_highlights: summarize the learnings, institutional learning

speaker: Ronny Kohavi
text: Document it. We had a large deck internally of these successes and failures, and we encourage people to look at them. The other thing that's very beneficial is just to have your whole history of experiments and do some ability to search by keywords.
text_ko: 문서로 남겨 두세요. 저희는 내부적으로 이런 성공·실패 사례를 모아둔 큰 슬라이드 덱(deck)이 있었고, 사람들에게 그걸 보라고 권장해요. 또 정말 유용한 건 전체 실험(experiments) 이력을 남겨서 키워드(keywords)로 검색할 수 있게 해두는 거예요.
text_zh: 把这些都记录下来。我们内部有一套很全的材料，把这些成功和失败的案例都整理在里面，我们也鼓励大家多去看看。另外还有一个特别有用的做法，就是把你们所有的实验历史都保存好，然后可以按关键词来搜索查找。
text_es: Documéntalo todo. Nosotros teníamos internamente una presentación bien grande con todos estos éxitos y fracasos, y animábamos a la gente a revisarla. Lo otro que es súper útil es tener todo el historial de experimentos y poder buscar por palabras clave.
context: Lenny asks for practical advice on how teams can remember surprising experiment results when people leave the company years later. Ronny recommends systematic documentation and searchable experiment histories, noting that at Microsoft they were running 20-25,000 experiments per year, making searchability crucial for finding relevant past learnings before launching new experiments.
vocabulary_highlights: large deck internally, search by keywords

speaker: Ryan Hoover
speaker_expertise: Company Building, Product Management, Venture Capital
text: I first opened up my DMs- I had 'em closed, which is like traditionally the default on Twitter for a long time. 'Cause I was like, "Oh, if I open them up, I'll just get a bunch of spam and I don't need another inbox to- to call through." I opened it up quietly and, um, actually didn't get a lot of spam, uh, surprisingly.
text_ko: 처음에 다이렉트 메시지(DMs)를 열었어요 — 원래 닫아놨었거든요. 트위터에서는 오랫동안 그게 기본 설정이었고요. '열어 놓으면 스팸(spam)이 막 올 거고, 또 하나 더 확인할 받은편지함은 필요 없을 거야'라고 생각했어요. 그래서 조용히 열어봤는데, 의외로 스팸이 많이 오지 않았어요.
text_zh: 我一开始把私信功能打开了——之前一直关着的，Twitter上默认设置就是关闭的嘛，用了很长时间都这样。因为我当时想，"哎呀，要是打开了，肯定会收到一大堆垃圾信息，我可不想再多一个收件箱要处理。" 结果我悄悄打开了，嗯，其实没收到什么垃圾信息，还挺意外的。
text_es: Primero abrí mis mensajes directos - los tenía cerrados, que es como tradicionalmente viene por defecto en Twitter desde hace mucho tiempo. Porque pensé, "Ay, si los abro, me van a llegar un montón de spam y no necesito otra bandeja de entrada que revisar." Los abrí sin hacer ruido y, eh, la verdad es que no me llegó tanto spam, sorprendentemente.
context: Lenny asks Ryan about his practice of offering free advice to founders who DM him on Twitter. Ryan explains how he initially hesitated to open his direct messages because he expected to receive spam, but was surprised to find that wasn't the case. This led to him actively inviting founders to reach out for advice, which he then sometimes shares publicly (anonymized) as a form of micro-blogging.
vocabulary_highlights: call through, opened it up quietly

speaker: Ryan Hoover
speaker_expertise: Company Building, Product Management, Venture Capital
text: And maybe the biggest surprise was a lot of people are pretty vulnerable. These are strangers, founders who DM me saying, "Hey, I'm- we have three months runway left. We're running out of money. Here's a situation. What advice do you have?" Or just things that, you know, everyone has to wear this unfortunate mask is kind of the way I- what I used to describe it.
text_ko: 아마 제일 놀랐던 건 생각보다 많은 사람들이 꽤 취약하다는 점이에요. 모르는 사람들, 창업자들(founders)이 다이렉트 메시지(DM)로 “저희 런웨이(runway)가 3개월밖에 안 남았어요. 돈이 거의 다 떨어져가고 있어요. 이런 상황인데 조언해주실 수 있나요?”라고 보내요. 혹은 다들 어쩔 수 없이 불행한 가면을 써야 한다는 식의 얘기들인데, 제가 예전부터 그렇게 표현하곤 했던 방식이에요.
text_zh: 最让我意外的可能是，很多人其实挺脆弱的。这些素不相识的创始人会私信我说："嘿，我们——我们还有三个月的runway（资金跑道）就用完了，快没钱了。情况就是这样，你有什么建议吗？"或者聊一些别的事情，你知道的，每个人都得戴着这种让人无奈的面具，我以前是这么形容的。
text_es: Y tal vez la sorpresa más grande fue que mucha gente es bastante vulnerable. Son desconocidos, fundadores que me escriben por DM diciéndome: "Oye, nos quedan tres meses de runway, se nos está acabando el dinero. Esta es nuestra situación. ¿Qué consejo nos das?" O simplemente cosas que, ya sabes, todo mundo tiene que ponerse esta máscara desafortunada, así es como yo solía describirlo.
context: Lenny asks what Ryan has learned from founders who DM him questions. Ryan explains that he was surprised by how vulnerable and authentic people are willing to be in private messages, sharing serious problems like running out of funding. He reflects on how founders typically have to project confidence publicly while dealing with significant challenges privately.
vocabulary_highlights: three months runway left, wear this unfortunate mask

speaker: Ryan Hoover
speaker_expertise: Company Building, Product Management, Venture Capital
text: I do spend time, ironically, like. challenging founders sometimes when they're thinking about raising or thinking about an idea to- to not raise. Um, people who are in tech, uh, especially, are certain bubbles of tech, that's the default. It's like, "The first thing I do, I have an idea, now let's go raise money."
text_ko: 아이러니하게도 저는 창업자들(founders)이 자금 조달(raising)을 고민하거나 아예 안 하겠다고 생각할 때 그 생각에 대해 가끔 도전적으로 질문을 던지며 시간을 써요. 특히 테크(tech) 쪽 사람들은, 어떤 기술 버블(tech bubbles) 안에서는 그게 기본값이에요. '아이디어가 생기면 제일 먼저 투자 유치(raise money)를 하자'라는 식이죠.
text_zh: 我确实会花时间，挺讽刺的，就是有时候会质疑一些创始人，当他们在考虑融资或者在考虑某个想法的时候，我会建议他们别急着融资。搞科技的人，特别是在某些科技圈子里的人，融资已经成了默认选项了。就像"我一有想法，第一件事就是去融钱。"
text_es: Me paso tiempo, irónicamente, desafiando a los fundadores a veces cuando están pensando en levantar capital o considerando una idea para que... para que no levanten capital. La gente que está en tech, especialmente en ciertas burbujas del tech, eso es lo normal. Es como, "Lo primero que hago, tengo una idea, ahora vamos a buscar financiamiento."
context: Lenny asks Ryan about his advice to founders considering whether to start a company, given how difficult startups are. Ryan explains that he often challenges founders who assume they need to raise venture capital immediately after having an idea. He points out that in certain tech circles, fundraising has become the default first step, even when it may not be necessary or appropriate.
vocabulary_highlights: certain bubbles of tech, that's the default
topics: Starting a Company, Fundraising, Decision Making

speaker: Ryan Hoover
speaker_expertise: Company Building, Product Management, Venture Capital
text: I think it's super important that founders see a line of sight to work on this for ... I think my rule of thumb is a decade, just do you see yourself working on this for a decade? And maybe it's not a decade that you actually work on it. It probably won't, it either, it'll probably fail before then as most startups do, but I think it's a good litmus test for yourself.
text_ko: 창업자들이 이 일을 앞으로도 계속할 수 있다는 확신을 갖고 있는 게 정말 중요하다고 생각해요. 제 경험상 기준은 대략 10년이에요. 스스로 '내가 이걸 10년 동안 해도 괜찮을까?'라고 물어보는 거예요. 실제로 10년을 채 일하게 될지는 모르고, 대부분의 스타트업처럼 그 전에 실패할 가능성이 더 커요. 그래도 스스로를 평가해 보는 좋은 리트머스 테스트(litmus test)가 된다고 생각해요.
text_zh: 我觉得创始人得能看到自己会在这个项目上坚持下去，这点特别重要。我的经验法则就是十年，你能想象自己在这件事上干十年吗？当然不一定真的要干满十年，大概率也干不到，就像大部分创业公司一样，可能早就挂了。但我觉得这是个不错的试金石，可以测试一下自己。
text_es: Creo que es súper importante que los fundadores se vean trabajando en esto a largo plazo... Mi regla general es una década, ¿te ves trabajando en esto por diez años? Y tal vez no sean diez años los que realmente le dediques. Probablemente no sea así, lo más probable es que fracase antes como pasa con la mayoría de startups, pero creo que es una buena prueba de fuego para uno mismo.
context: Ryan continues discussing his advice for founders considering starting a company. He explains his framework for evaluating startup commitment - founders should be able to envision working on their idea for a decade. While acknowledging that most startups fail before reaching that timeframe, he believes this long-term perspective serves as an important litmus test for genuine passion and commitment to the problem they're trying to solve.
vocabulary_highlights: see a line of sight, rule of thumb, good litmus test

speaker: Ryan Hoover
speaker_expertise: Company Building, Product Management, Venture Capital
text: I don't know how to articulate that- that feeling, but that flutter in your stomach that you wake up with in the morning of just anxiety and stress and- and worry. Um, being a CEO or founder makes it slightly harder, uh, in some ways, because you still have to put on this mask.
text_ko: 그 느낌을 어떻게 말로 표현해야 할지 잘 모르겠어요 — 아침에 눈 뜰 때부터 가슴이 두근거리고 불안하고 스트레스와 걱정이 밀려오는 그런 느낌요. 최고경영자(CEO)나 창업자(founder)로서 보면 어떤 면에서는 그게 조금 더 힘들어요, 왜냐하면 여전히 겉으로는 괜찮은 척하는 가면을 써야 하거든요.
text_zh: 我不知道怎么形容那种感觉，就是早上醒来肚子里翻江倒海的那种焦虑、压力和担忧。当CEO或创始人会让这种感觉更难受，因为你还得装出一副若无其事的样子。
text_es: No sé cómo expresar esa... esa sensación, pero esas mariposas en el estómago con las que te despiertas por la mañana, pura ansiedad y estrés y... y preocupación. Eh, ser CEO o fundador lo hace un poco más difícil, eh, de cierta manera, porque aún tienes que ponerte esa máscara.
context: Ryan is describing the emotional toll of being a founder during difficult periods at Product Hunt. He's explaining to Lenny the physical manifestation of startup stress - the stomach flutter of anxiety upon waking. He emphasizes how being in a leadership position compounds this difficulty because founders must project confidence externally while dealing with internal anxiety, creating additional pressure beyond the underlying business challenges.
vocabulary_highlights: flutter in your stomach, put on this mask

speaker: Ryan Hoover
speaker_expertise: Company Building, Product Management, Venture Capital
text: The biggest surprise has probably been ... There are cases when I didn't think the company would make it. I- uh, either the product wasn't working, and you know, many months had passed, and it was very clear that they're- they- well, to me, I thought it was clear that, okay, that this probably isn't gonna work out. In my head I kinda wrote it off.
text_ko: 가장 놀랐던 건 아마도… 어떤 경우에는 제가 그 회사가 버티지 못할 거라고 생각했을 때예요. 저, 음, 제품이 제대로 작동하지 않거나 몇 달이 지나도 별 진전이 없어서 제게는 ‘아, 이건 안 될 것 같다’가 너무 분명해 보였어요. 그래서 속으로는 이미 접어뒀어요.
text_zh: 最大的意外可能就是...有些时候我觉得这家公司肯定要完蛋了。我...呃，要么就是产品根本搞不定，你知道的，好几个月过去了，我觉得很明显他们...他们...反正在我看来，就是很明显嘛，这事儿八成是黄了。我心里基本上已经把它给划掉了。
text_es: La sorpresa más grande probablemente ha sido... Hay casos en los que pensé que la empresa no lo iba a lograr. Yo... eh, o el producto no funcionaba, y sabes, habían pasado muchos meses, y para mí era muy claro que ellos... bueno, yo pensaba que era obvio que, okay, esto probablemente no va a salir adelante. En mi mente ya lo había dado por perdido.
context: Lenny asks Ryan what has surprised him most about angel investing. Ryan explains that his biggest surprise has been seeing companies he had mentally written off as failures eventually succeed through pivots or unexpected breakthroughs. This taught him never to count portfolio companies out until they're definitively done, highlighting the unpredictable nature of startup journeys and the importance of backing resilient founders.
vocabulary_highlights: wrote it off, count a portfolio company out

speaker: Ryan J. Salva
speaker_expertise: Product Management, AI/ML Products, Community Building
text: Copilot is essentially that magnified by many lines of code. It is multi-line autocomplete that is fundamentally powered by an AI model called CodeX, which is a derivative of another one that you might be familiar with, GPT-3. When you are in the editor, it could be VS Code, it could be IntelliJ, it could be them, essentially, as you are typing, Copilot will provide suggestions usually in kind of this italicized gray text that is really, to your point, kind of magical what it's able to infer.
text_ko: 코파일럿(Copilot)은 본질적으로 많은 코드 라인으로 확장된 형태예요. 여러 줄 자동완성(multi-line autocomplete) 기능인데, 기본적으로 코덱스(CodeX)라는 AI 모델로 구동돼요. 그 모델은 익숙하실지도 모를 GPT-3(GPT-3)에서 파생된 거예요. 에디터(editor) — 예를 들어 VS Code(Visual Studio Code)나 인텔리제이(IntelliJ) — 에서 타이핑하면, 코파일럿이 보통 기울인 회색 텍스트로 제안을 보여주는데, 말씀하신 대로 무엇을 추론해내는지가 정말 마법 같아요.
text_zh: Copilot其实就是把这个功能放大了很多倍，涉及到很多行代码。它本质上是个多行自动补全工具，背后用的是一个叫CodeX的AI模型，这个模型是从GPT-3衍生出来的，GPT-3你们应该都听说过。当你在编辑器里工作的时候，不管是VS Code还是IntelliJ什么的，你一边敲代码，Copilot就会给你提建议，通常是用那种斜体的灰色字显示出来，说实话，它能推断出什么东西来，真的挺神奇的。
text_es: Copilot es básicamente eso mismo pero amplificado por muchísimas líneas de código. Es como un autocompletado multilínea que funciona con un modelo de IA llamado CodeX, que viene de otro que seguramente conoces, el GPT-3. Cuando estás en el editor, ya sea VS Code, IntelliJ, o cualquier otro, mientras vas escribiendo, Copilot te va dando sugerencias normalmente en esa letra gris en cursiva que, como dices, es casi mágico lo que logra inferir.
context: Lenny asks Ryan to explain what GitHub Copilot is for listeners who aren't familiar with it. Ryan describes how Copilot evolved from basic autocomplete features that developers have used for decades. He explains that while traditional autocomplete only suggests simple completions like variable names, Copilot uses advanced AI to suggest entire blocks of code based on context, comments, and surrounding code patterns.
vocabulary_highlights: magnified by many lines, fundamentally powered by, italicized gray text, what it's able to infer

speaker: Ryan J. Salva
speaker_expertise: Product Management, AI/ML Products, Community Building
text: The labor of remembering what's the order of parameters that need to come into a particular API, or hey, what's the particular syntax of this thing I'm supposed to do, or oh, I've got to create a bunch of dummy data that is days of the week or months in the year. That's just labor. It's not creating. It's just typing.
text_ko: 어떤 애플리케이션 프로그래밍 인터페이스(API)에 어떤 파라미터(parameters)를 어떤 순서로 넣어야 하는지 기억해내거나, 이걸 어떻게 써야 하는지의 정확한 구문(syntax)을 떠올리거나, 요일(days of the week)이나 연중 월(months in the year) 같은 더미 데이터(dummy data)를 잔뜩 만들어야 하는 건 그냥 노동이에요. 창조적인 일이 아니라 단순히 타이핑하는 거예요.
text_zh: 记住某个API(API)参数的顺序，或者搞清楚这个功能到底怎么写，还有创建一堆像星期几、月份这样的测试数据，这些都是纯体力活。这不是在做创造性的工作，就是在敲键盘而已。
text_es: El trabajo de recordar cuál es el orden de los parámetros que van en una API específica, o bueno, cuál es la sintaxis exacta de esto que tengo que hacer, o ay, tengo que crear un montón de datos de prueba que sean días de la semana o meses del año. Eso es puro trabajo manual. No es crear nada. Es solo teclear.
context: Ryan continues explaining the value proposition of Copilot by describing common frustrations developers face. He argues that much of a developer's time is spent on mundane tasks like remembering API syntax or creating test data, rather than the creative problem-solving aspects of programming. Ryan positions Copilot as a tool that eliminates this 'busy work' so developers can focus on the creative and strategic aspects of coding.
vocabulary_highlights: bunch of dummy data, That's just labor

speaker: Ryan J. Salva
speaker_expertise: Product Management, AI/ML Products, Community Building
text: We had actually created a snapshot of GitHub's public code for what we call the Arctic Code Vault, right? Essentially, this is up in like way in the Northlands of Finland, there's a seed vault. We were like, you know what? Seed vaults are really there to preserve the diversity of the world's flora in seeds in case of some crazy either natural or manmade disaster. But another really important asset to the world is our code, our open source.
text_ko: 사실 저희는 GitHub 공개 코드의 스냅샷(snapshot)을 만들어서 '아틱 코드 볼트(Arctic Code Vault)'라고 부르는 곳에 보관했어요. 기본적으로 그건 핀란드 북부 한참 위쪽에 있는 종자 저장고(seed vault) 같은 곳이에요. 그래서 '종자 저장고는 자연 재해든 인재든 말도 안 되는 일이 생겼을 때 세계 식물의 다양성을 씨앗 형태로 보존하려는 거지'라고 생각했어요. 그런데 또 하나 세상에 정말 중요한 자산이 바로 우리 코드, 즉 오픈소스(open source)라는 점이었어요.
text_zh: 其实我们为了所谓的北极代码库(Arctic Code Vault)创建了GitHub公开代码的快照，对吧？基本上就是这样的，在芬兰北部那边有个种子库。我们就想，你知道吗？种子库的存在就是为了保护全世界植物种子的多样性，以防万一出现什么疯狂的天灾人祸。但是对世界来说，我们的代码、我们的开源项目也是另一个非常重要的资产。
text_es: Habíamos creado una instantánea de todo el código público de GitHub para lo que llamamos el Arctic Code Vault, ¿verdad? Básicamente, esto está allá arriba en el norte de Finlandia, donde hay un banco de semillas. Y dijimos, ¿sabes qué? Los bancos de semillas están ahí para preservar la diversidad de la flora mundial en caso de algún desastre loco, ya sea natural o causado por el hombre. Pero otro recurso súper importante para el mundo es nuestro código, nuestro código abierto (open source).
context: Ryan tells the origin story of how Copilot began when OpenAI was aggressively downloading GitHub's repositories for training data. He explains that GitHub had previously created the Arctic Code Vault - a physical preservation project storing code on silver film in Finland, similar to seed vaults that preserve plant genetics. This existing dataset became the foundation for training the AI model that would become Copilot.
vocabulary_highlights: way in the Northlands, preserve the diversity, some crazy either natural or manmade disaster

speaker: Ryan J. Salva
speaker_expertise: Product Management, AI/ML Products, Community Building
text: The original team that was working on Copilot at GitHub was the team that we call GitHub Next. Essentially their job is to work on second and third horizon projects. What some folks might call moonshots, right? Things that we never really expect work in the next one or two years, but might three, five years down the line actually turn into something meaningful.
text_ko: 원래 깃허브에서 코파일럿(Copilot)을 담당하던 팀이 바로 깃허브 넥스트(GitHub Next)예요. 요컨대 이들의 일은 2차·3차 호라이즌 프로젝트(second and third horizon projects)를 진행하는 건데요, 어떤 분들은 그런 걸 문샷(moonshots)이라고 부르기도 해요. 보통 1~2년 안에 바로 성과가 날 거라고 기대하진 않지만, 3년·5년쯤 지나면 실제로 의미 있는 결과로 이어질 수도 있는 일들이에요.
text_zh: 当时在GitHub开发Copilot的那个团队就是我们说的GitHub Next团队。基本上他们的工作就是搞一些第二、第三层面的项目。有些人可能会叫这种moonshot项目，对吧？就是那种我们其实也不指望在一两年内能搞出什么名堂，但可能三五年后真能做成点什么有意义的东西。
text_es: El equipo original que estaba trabajando en Copilot en GitHub era el equipo que llamamos GitHub Next. Básicamente su trabajo es enfocarse en proyectos de segundo y tercer horizonte. Lo que algunos podrían llamar moonshots, ¿no? Cosas que realmente no esperamos que funcionen en los próximos uno o dos años, pero que tal vez en tres, cinco años puedan convertirse en algo realmente significativo.
context: Lenny asks whether there was a clear moment when leadership decided to double down on Copilot as a major investment. Ryan explains GitHub's organizational structure for innovation, describing GitHub Next as their R&D team focused on long-term experimental projects. He defines horizon projects as initiatives organized by time and uncertainty rather than calendar dates, with different horizons representing different levels of risk and timeline expectations.
vocabulary_highlights: second and third horizon projects, moonshots, down the line actually turn into something meaningful
topics: Product Management, Strategy & Planning, Leadership & Management

speaker: Ryan J. Salva
speaker_expertise: Product Management, AI/ML Products, Community Building
text: Making sure that you've got a good mix of engineers who are comfortable maintaining a service, as well as engineers and researchers who are really thinking about, what is the idea that we've created, what is the new thing that we've brought to market, and can bring that vision to it.
text_ko: 서비스를 안정적으로 운영·유지보수(service maintenance)할 수 있는 엔지니어들과, 우리가 만들어낸 아이디어가 무엇인지, 시장에 새로 선보이는 것(go-to-market)이 무엇인지 깊이 고민하고 그 비전을 실현할 수 있는 엔지니어·연구자들이 고루 섞여 있어야 해요.
text_zh: 你得确保团队里既有能稳稳当当维护服务的工程师，也要有那些真正在思考的工程师和研究人员——就是那种会问"我们到底创造了什么东西？我们给市场带来了什么新玩意儿？"然后能把这个愿景真正落地的人。
text_es: Tienes que asegurarte de tener una buena mezcla de ingenieros que se sientan cómodos manteniendo un servicio, y también ingenieros e investigadores que realmente se enfoquen en pensar: ¿cuál es la idea que hemos creado?, ¿qué es lo nuevo que hemos traído al mercado?, y que puedan aportar esa visión al proyecto.
context: Ryan shares lessons learned about transitioning experimental R&D projects to operational products within large companies. He emphasizes the importance of creating hybrid teams that combine researchers who understand the original innovation with engineers who have the skills to scale and maintain production services. This advice comes from GitHub's experience moving Copilot from their experimental Next team to their production engineering teams.
vocabulary_highlights: good mix of engineers, bring that vision to it
topics: Product Management, Leadership & Management, Strategy & Planning

speaker: Ryan J. Salva
speaker_expertise: Product Management, AI/ML Products, Community Building
text: As a general rule, as a general principle, I certainly try to make sure that we're always reserving some capacity for bold, audacious experimental research projects. You can think of those really uncertain bets as being five to 10% of the team's capacity. About 25, maybe 30% of the team's capacity should generally be on just operations.
text_ko: 원칙적으로 저는 항상 팀 역량(capacity)의 일부를 대담하고 과감한 실험형 연구 프로젝트(experimental research projects)에 쓸 여지를 남겨두려고 해요. 그런 정말 불확실한 베팅은 팀 역량의 대략 5~10% 정도로 보면 되고요. 반면에 약 25%, 많아야 30% 정도는 일반적인 운영(operations)에 할당돼야 해요.
text_zh: 一般来说，我肯定会确保团队始终留出一些精力去做那些大胆的、有挑战性的实验研究项目。你可以把这些高风险的尝试理解为占团队精力的5%到10%。大概25%，也许30%的团队精力应该主要放在日常运营上。
text_es: Como regla general, siempre trato de asegurarme de que estemos reservando cierta capacidad para proyectos de investigación experimental audaces, ¿sabes? Puedes pensar en esas apuestas más arriesgadas como un 5 a 10% de la capacidad del equipo. Y alrededor del 25, tal vez 30% de la capacidad del equipo debería estar enfocada en operaciones del día a día.
context: Lenny asks Ryan for advice on balancing bold bets versus incremental improvements when managing product portfolios at large companies. Ryan provides specific percentage recommendations for resource allocation: 5-10% on experimental moonshots, 25-30% on maintaining existing products, and about 60% on incremental improvements to in-market products. He notes this framework works for larger teams, while startups typically must go all-in on single big bets.
vocabulary_highlights: bold, audacious experimental research projects, really uncertain bets, just operations
topics: Product Management, Strategy & Planning, Leadership & Management

speaker: Ryan Singer
text: I often use this analogy of if you're doing a home renovation, you can have the most beautiful rendering of the new bedroom and we're going to have these lamps on the side of the bed that are coming out from the wall. But if you haven't checked if there's electricity in that wall there or not, it's going to drastically change the cost and the time and everything.
text_ko: 제가 자주 하는 비유가 있어요. 집을 리모델링(home renovation)한다고 생각해 보세요. 새 침실의 가장 멋진 렌더링(rendering)을 갖고, 침대 옆에 벽에서 나오는 조명을 달기로 했어요. 그런데 그 벽 안에 전기 배선(electrical wiring)이 있는지 확인을 안 했다면 비용이랑 공사 기간, 결과까지 모두 크게 달라져요.
text_zh: 我经常打这样一个比方：就像你装修房子，你可能设计了一个特别漂亮的卧室效果图，床两边要装那种从墙里伸出来的壁灯，看起来特别棒。但是如果你事先没搞清楚那面墙里到底有没有电线，那成本啊、工期啊什么的都得大改，完全不是一回事了。
text_es: Siempre uso esta analogía: si estás renovando tu casa, puedes tener el diseño más bonito del dormitorio nuevo, con estas lámparas súper lindas que van a salir de la pared junto a la cama. Pero si no te fijaste antes si hay instalación eléctrica en esa pared, te va a cambiar completamente el presupuesto, los tiempos y todo el proyecto.
context: Ryan uses this home renovation analogy to explain why technical feasibility must be explored during the shaping phase, not after committing to build something. He's illustrating how beautiful designs or plans can fall apart when they encounter technical reality - just like planning wall-mounted lamps without checking if electrical wiring exists in that wall. This speaks to the core Shape Up principle of de-risking projects upfront rather than discovering problems mid-build.
vocabulary_highlights: drastically change, rendering

speaker: Ryan Singer
text: What we need to do in a shaping session is we come out with some kind of diagram where engineers, product and design, they're saying, 'We understand that.' So the first thing is we are not going to start something unless we can see the end from the beginning. We're not going to take a big concept and then say, 'What's the estimate for this thing?'
text_ko: 셰이핑 세션(shaping session)에서 우리가 할 일은 엔지니어, 프로덕트(product), 디자인(design)팀이 모두 '이해했어요'라고 말할 수 있는 어떤 다이어그램(diagram)을 갖고 나오는 거예요. 그래서 첫 번째 원칙은 처음부터 끝을 볼 수 없으면 시작하지 않는다는 거예요. 큰 콘셉트만 던져놓고 '이거 견적(estimate) 얼마예요?'라고 묻는 식으로는 진행하지 않아요.
text_zh: 在塑形会议(shaping session)里，我们要做的就是画出一个图，让工程师、产品和设计的同事都能说"这个我们明白了"。所以第一点就是，如果从一开始就看不到结果会是什么样，我们就不会启动这个项目。我们不会拿一个很大的概念然后问"这东西要多长时间能做完？"
text_es: Lo que tenemos que lograr en una sesión de shaping es salir con algún tipo de diagrama donde los ingenieros, producto y diseño digan: "Ah, ya entendemos". Entonces lo primero es que no vamos a arrancar nada a menos que podamos ver el final desde el principio. No vamos a agarrar un concepto enorme y después preguntar "¿Cuánto tiempo le calculamos a esto?"
context: Ryan explains a core Shape Up principle about project clarity before starting work. Instead of estimating big, vague concepts, Shape Up requires creating clear diagrams during shaping sessions where all team members - engineers, product managers, and designers - can understand exactly what needs to be built. This ensures everyone can visualize the end result before committing engineering time to the project.
vocabulary_highlights: big concept

speaker: Ryan Singer
text: We're going to go the other way around and we're going to say, what is the maximum amount of time we're willing to go before we actually finish something? How do we come up with a idea that's going to work in the amount of time that the business is interested in spending?
text_ko: 반대로 접근해볼게요. 우리가 실제로 뭔가를 끝내기 전에 기꺼이 들일 수 있는 최대 시간, 즉 타임박스(timebox)를 먼저 정하는 거예요. 그다음 비즈니스가 기꺼이 투자하려는 시간 안에 제대로 작동할 아이디어를 어떻게 찾아낼지 고민하는 거예요.
text_zh: 我们要反过来思考，先问自己：我们最多愿意花多长时间才能真正把一件事做完？然后再想，怎么在公司愿意投入的时间范围内，找到一个真正行得通的点子？
text_es: Vamos a darle la vuelta al asunto y vamos a preguntarnos: ¿cuál es el tiempo máximo que estamos dispuestos a invertir antes de terminar algo de verdad? ¿Cómo se nos ocurre una idea que funcione en el tiempo que la empresa está dispuesta a gastar?
context: Ryan describes the fundamental Shape Up approach of working backward from time constraints rather than forward from scope. Instead of estimating how long a feature will take to build, Shape Up starts by setting a maximum time budget (appetite) and then shapes the solution to fit within that constraint. This forces teams to make deliberate trade-offs and ensures projects don't drag on indefinitely.
vocabulary_highlights: the other way around, come up with
topics: Product Management, Strategy & Planning, Decision Making

speaker: Ryan Singer
text: There was always this really intense urgency from both Jason and David, 'We've got to get to something we can ship. We have to finish this and move on. We have to get to something that's done.' There was just no tolerance for big things that got fuzzy and started to drag.
text_ko: 제이슨과 데이비드 두 사람 모두 항상 진짜 강한 긴박감을 갖고 있었어요. "우리는 출시(ship)할 수 있는 걸 빨리 만들어야 해요. 이걸 끝내고 넘어가야 해요. 완성된 상태에 도달해야 해요." 막연해지면서 늘어지는 큰 프로젝트들은 전혀 용납하지 않았어요.
text_zh: 杰森和大卫两个人总是特别着急，就是那种"咱们得赶紧弄出能发布的东西来，必须把这个搞定然后继续下一个，一定要做出成品来"。他们就是受不了那种搞得模模糊糊、拖拖拉拉的大项目。
text_es: Siempre había esta urgencia súper intensa de parte de Jason y David: "Tenemos que llegar a algo que podamos lanzar. Hay que terminar esto y seguir adelante. Tenemos que llegar a algo que esté listo." Simplemente no había tolerancia para proyectos grandes que se volvían confusos y empezaban a alargarse.
context: Ryan describes the cultural foundation that led to Shape Up at Basecamp's early days. Founders Jason Fried and David Heinemeier Hansson maintained intense urgency around shipping, refusing to let projects become unclear or drag on indefinitely. This drive to reach concrete, shippable outcomes quickly became a core principle that later evolved into the formal Shape Up methodology when the company needed to scale this approach.
vocabulary_highlights: no tolerance for, got fuzzy, started to drag

speaker: Ryan Singer
text: Those sessions with Jason, they were these short, very, very intense sessions where you're trying to crack the nut together. Where's the idea? What's the concept? How can we go... What's this thing that we're going to go and 10 hours later, right, David's going to come back and we're going to be like, 'This is awesome. This thing works and it does something we're excited about,' right?
text_ko: 제이슨과 했던 그 세션들은 짧지만 정말 강렬하고 집중된 시간이었어요. 같이 머리 맞대고 핵심을 풀어보려는 자리였죠. 아이디어는 어디에 있지? 콘셉트는 뭐지? 어떻게 해볼 수 있지… 10시간 뒤에 데이비드가 돌아왔을 때 ‘이거 정말 멋지다. 이게 작동하고 우리가 기대하던 걸 해주네’라고 말하게 될 그런 걸 어떻게 만들어낼지 고민하는 시간이었어요, 그렇죠?
text_zh: 跟Jason开的那些会，都是短时间但特别紧张的头脑风暴，大家一起想办法解决问题。想法在哪儿？核心概念是什么？我们怎么能够...就是找到那个点，然后10个小时之后，David回来了，我们就能说"太棒了！这个方案行得通，而且正是我们想要的那种效果"，你知道吧？
text_es: Esas sesiones con Jason eran súper cortas pero intensísimas, ¿sabes? Era como tratar de resolver el problema juntos. ¿Dónde está la idea? ¿Cuál es el concepto? ¿Cómo podemos... qué es esa cosa que vamos a desarrollar y que 10 horas después David va a regresar y vamos a decir "Esto está padrísimo. Esta cosa funciona y hace algo que nos emociona"?
context: Ryan describes the early collaborative sessions with Jason Fried that became the foundation for Shape Up's shaping process. These were intense, focused sessions aimed at 'cracking the nut' - finding the core idea that could be built quickly and effectively. With David only available 10 hours per week for programming, they needed absolute clarity on what to build before he started coding, which forced them to do deep thinking upfront.
vocabulary_highlights: crack the nut together
topics: Product Management, Strategy & Planning, Coaching & Development

speaker: Ryan Singer
text: That was one of those moments where you're like, 'Oh, this isn't going to automatically, organically just keep it spreading as we hire forever.' You know what I mean? We did reach a point where it's like, 'Oh, we're going to have to figure out when this goes well, why does it go well and what do we do differently and how do we formalize that so it's reproducible as we keep onboarding more people?'
text_ko: 그건 '아, 이건 우리가 계속 사람을 뽑는다고 해서 저절로 자연스럽게 계속 퍼지진 않겠구나' 하고 느끼는 순간 중 하나였어요. 무슨 말인지 알죠? 결국 '이게 잘 될 때 왜 잘 되는지, 뭘 다르게 해야 하는지, 그리고 사람들을 더 많이 온보딩(onboarding)할수록 그걸 재현할 수 있게 어떻게 체계화할지' 알아내야 한다는 생각이 들었어요.
text_zh: 那一刻我们就意识到，"哎呀，这个东西不会因为我们一直招人就自然而然地传承下去。"你懂我意思吧？我们确实到了一个节点，就是"好吧，我们得搞清楚什么时候做得好，为什么做得好，我们哪里做得不一样，怎么把这些东西规范化，这样以后新人入职(onboarding)的时候就能复制这套做法？"
text_es: Fue uno de esos momentos donde dices, "Ah, esto no va a seguir extendiéndose automáticamente por sí solo conforme vayamos contratando más gente." ¿Me entiendes? Llegamos a un punto donde dijimos, "Oye, vamos a tener que averiguar cuándo esto funciona bien, por qué funciona bien y qué hacemos diferente, y cómo lo formalizamos para que sea replicable mientras sigamos incorporando más personas."
context: Ryan recounts the moment Basecamp realized their organic way of working wouldn't scale indefinitely. After about 10 years of organic growth, they encountered their first project that didn't go well due to team members not understanding the implicit processes. This was the catalyst for formalizing their approach into what became Shape Up - they needed to systematize what had been working intuitively so new hires could participate effectively.
vocabulary_highlights: organically just keep it spreading, formalize that so it's reproducible

speaker: Ryan Singer
text: You can't put 10 pounds of crap in a five pound bag. So, it's a high academic statement and we can't just take any project, no matter how giant it is, and then throw it at a team and say, 'Figure it out and ship something meaningful in six weeks by cutting away scope,' right?
text_ko: 5파운드 가방에 10파운드 짐을 넣을 수는 없어요. 이건 이론적으로는 맞는 말이긴 한데, 아무리 프로젝트가 거대해도 무작정 팀에 떠맡기고 '범위(scope)를 잘라내서 6주 만에 알아서 해결하고 의미 있는 결과물을 출시(ship)해'라고 할 순 없어요, 그렇죠?
text_zh: 你不能往五磅的袋子里塞十磅的垃圾。所以说，这是个很学术的说法，但道理就是我们不能随便接个项目，不管这项目有多大，然后就扔给团队说"你们想办法，削减一些功能范围，六周内搞出个像样的东西来"，对吧？
text_es: No puedes meter diez kilos de porquería en una bolsa de cinco kilos. Entonces, es una declaración muy académica y no podemos simplemente tomar cualquier proyecto, por más gigante que sea, y luego tirárselo a un equipo y decirles: "Resuelvan esto y entreguen algo que tenga sentido en seis semanas reduciendo el alcance", ¿verdad?
context: Ryan, quoting Bob Moesta, explains why proper shaping is crucial before giving teams time-boxed projects. He's addressing a common Shape Up misapplication where teams try to take massive, undefined projects and force them into six-week cycles by cutting scope. This approach fails because without proper upfront shaping work to define what's actually achievable, teams can't meaningfully reduce an oversized project to fit the time constraint.
vocabulary_highlights: 10 pounds of crap in a five pound bag, cutting away scope

speaker: Sachin Monga
speaker_expertise: Product Management, Consumer Products, Growth Strategy
text: I really think that we're just starting into this golden era of what it might mean to be a writer on the internet. The economic model for supporting great writing on the internet has been generally pretty terrible for the entirety of the internet's history. But in the last year or so, even in the last few months, I think there's been so many really interesting success stories now from writers who might not even consider themselves writers.
text_ko: 저는 정말 이제 막 인터넷에서 작가로 활동한다는 것의 황금기가 시작된 것 같다고 생각해요. 인터넷 역사 전체를 통틀어 좋은 글을 경제적으로 지원하는 모델은 대체로 형편없었어요. 그런데 지난 1년, 특히 몇 달 사이에 스스로를 작가라고 생각하지 않을 사람들조차 만든 정말 흥미로운 성공 사례들이 많이 생겼다고 봐요.
text_zh: 我觉得我们现在才刚刚进入互联网写作的黄金时代。说实话，从互联网诞生到现在，在网上写好内容的商业模式一直都挺糟糕的。但是最近一年多，甚至就这几个月，我看到了很多特别有意思的成功案例，而且这些人可能自己都不觉得自己是什么作家。
text_es: Realmente creo que apenas estamos entrando en esta época dorada de lo que puede significar ser escritor en internet. El modelo económico para apoyar la buena escritura en línea ha sido bastante terrible durante toda la historia del internet. Pero en el último año más o menos, incluso en los últimos meses, creo que hemos visto muchas historias de éxito súper interesantes de escritores que ni siquiera se consideran a sí mismos como escritores.
context: Sachin is discussing his long-term vision for where Substack is heading as a product. He's explaining how the internet has historically failed to properly compensate quality writers, but Substack is changing this landscape. He mentions that beyond established writers like Matt Taibbi who joined early, there are now many newer writers finding success who don't even identify primarily as writers but are making substantial income from their work.
vocabulary_highlights: golden era, generally pretty terrible, success stories

speaker: Sachin Monga
speaker_expertise: Product Management, Consumer Products, Growth Strategy
text: We're still pretty early, but we have something going now. We have four product managers in addition to myself, and we have three essentially kind of full stack product teams now that have a PM and an engineering manager, a data person or a designer, engineers and things are starting to roll. We're finally emerging from this transition phase and it's been super fun.
text_ko: 아직 꽤 초반이긴 한데, 지금은 뭔가 돌아가고 있어요. 저 외에 프로덕트 매니저(product manager, PM)가 4명 있고, 사실상 PM과 엔지니어링 매니저(engineering manager), 데이터 담당자(data person)나 디자이너, 엔지니어로 구성된 풀스택 제품팀(full-stack product team)이 세 팀 생겨서 일이 서서히 굴러가기 시작했어요. 드디어 이 과도기(transition phase)를 벗어나고 있는데, 정말 재밌어요.
text_zh: 我们现在还算比较早期，不过已经有点起色了。除了我之外，我们现在有四个产品经理，还有三个基本上算是全栈的产品团队(full stack product teams)，每个团队都配了产品经理(PM)、工程经理、数据分析师或者设计师，还有工程师，现在事情开始步入正轨了。我们终于从那个转型期走出来了，这个过程还挺有意思的。
text_es: Todavía estamos bastante al inicio, pero ya tenemos algo en marcha. Tenemos cuatro product managers además de mí, y tenemos tres equipos de producto que son básicamente full stack con un PM y un engineering manager, alguien de datos o un diseñador, ingenieros y las cosas ya están empezando a fluir. Por fin estamos saliendo de esta fase de transición y ha sido súper divertido.
context: Lenny asks Sachin about how Substack's product team is structured and how it might evolve as they scale. Sachin explains that when he joined Substack a year ago, they had zero product managers, but they've now built out a proper product organization. He describes their current structure of three full-stack teams aligned around different user types rather than product features.
vocabulary_highlights: full stack product teams, things are starting to roll, emerging from this transition phase

speaker: Sachin Monga
speaker_expertise: Product Management, Consumer Products, Growth Strategy
text: I think the first thing was really treating my role in the beginning more as a facilitator than a decision maker when it comes to product. When I first joined, I felt like my main role was actually just solving that. And if nothing else, if Chris could have a really good sense of what all the teams are doing and if the teams knew where he was coming from and could start to get better at modeling him and his vision, that would be a win.
text_ko: 처음에는 제가 프로덕트(product)에 관해서는 의사결정자(decision maker)라기보다 퍼실리테이터(facilitator) 역할을 하는 게 더 맞다고 생각했어요. 합류 초반에는 제 주된 역할이 사실 그 문제를 푸는 것이라고 느꼈고요. 최소한 크리스가 각 팀이 뭘 하는지 잘 파악하고, 팀들이 크리스의 관점을 이해해서 크리스를 모델링(modeling)하고 그의 비전을 더 잘 반영할 수 있게 된다면 그건 큰 성공이에요.
text_zh: 我觉得最开始的时候，在产品这块儿，我更多是把自己当成一个协调者，而不是拍板的人。刚加入的时候，我觉得我的主要任务就是解决这个问题。换句话说，如果Chris能清楚地知道各个团队在干什么，各个团队也能理解他的想法，并且开始学会跟上他的节奏和愿景，那就算成功了。
text_es: Creo que lo primero fue enfocar mi puesto más como facilitador que como el que toma las decisiones del producto. Cuando llegué, sentí que mi trabajo principal era resolver eso. Y aunque no lograra nada más, si Chris podía tener una idea clara de lo que estaban haciendo todos los equipos, y si los equipos entendían su perspectiva y empezaban a alinearse mejor con su visión, ya sería un éxito.
context: Lenny asks about the challenge of being a head of product at a small company with a founder who has strong product opinions. Sachin explains his approach to working with Chris, Substack's CEO. Rather than trying to be the primary decision maker immediately, Sachin focused on being a bridge between Chris and the product teams, ensuring clear communication of vision and priorities as the company grew beyond the point where Chris could be involved in every decision.
vocabulary_highlights: treating my role, main role, modeling him and his vision

speaker: Sachin Monga
speaker_expertise: Product Management, Consumer Products, Growth Strategy
text: Maybe that leads into my answer to the second question, which is that's not really for everyone. I think there's almost like a personality type that has to be okay with being humbled all the time and feeling like you don't know what you're doing.
