text_ko: 저는 항상 이렇게 말해요. 당신이 '겪고 싶어 하는' 문제들에 맞춰 최적화하라고요. 예를 들어 고객들이 퍼널(funnel)을 잘 통과해서 성공감을 느끼고, 제품을 써서 가치를 얻은 다음에 "아, 그런데 이 플랫폼(platform)에도 필요해요", "이런 기능(capability)이 필요해요", "이걸 공유하고 싶어요"라고 말하게 되는 그런 문제들을 원한다는 거예요. 그런 문제들이 생기길 바라니까 지금 당장 그런 기능(features)을 만들지 마세요.
text_zh: 我总是跟他们说，要为你想要的问题做优化。你希望遇到的问题应该是客户顺利通过你的漏斗(funnel)，感到成功，使用你的产品并获得价值，然后对你说："哎，但是我需要在这个平台上用，或者我需要这个功能，或者我想能够分享这个。" 我的意思是你就想要这些问题。所以现在别急着做那些功能。
text_es: Siempre les digo que se enfoquen en los problemas que sí quieren tener. Quieren el problema de que los clientes pasen por su embudo (funnel), se sientan exitosos, usen su producto y obtengan valor, y después les digan: "Oye, pero lo necesito en esta plataforma, o necesito esta funcionalidad, o quiero poder compartir esto." O sea, esos son los problemas que quieren tener. Así que no desarrollen esas características ahorita.
context: Lenny asks Scott about his advice to only build half the features you want to build and how to decide which features to include in an MVP. Scott explains his philosophy of prioritizing the core user journey over additional features. He believes teams should focus on eliminating fundamental barriers that prevent users from experiencing value, rather than building nice-to-have features that users will only request once they're already engaged.
vocabulary_highlights: optimize for the problems you want to have, getting through your funnel, feeling successful

speaker: Scott Belsky
speaker_expertise: Product Management, Company Building, Product Design
text: In the first 30 seconds of using a new product, you are lazy, vain, and selfish. You want to get it done super quickly. You want to look good to your colleagues or to your friends. You want to feel successful very quickly by engaging in this product. You don't want to have to watch a tour or read anything, really endure any learning curve whatsoever.
text_ko: 새 제품을 처음 써보는 첫 30초 동안은 사람들은 게으르고, 허영심 많고, 이기적이에요. 일은 정말 빨리 끝내고 싶어하고, 동료나 친구들에게 잘 보이고 싶어해요. 이 제품을 쓰면서 금방 성공한 느낌을 받고 싶어해요. 제품 투어를 보거나 뭔가를 읽고 싶지 않고, 어떤 학습 곡선(learning curve)도 겪고 싶어하지 않아요.
text_zh: 用户在使用新产品的前30秒，基本上都是懒、爱面子、还很自私的。他们就想快速搞定，想在同事或朋友面前显得很厉害，想马上就有成就感。他们可不想看什么产品介绍，也不想读说明，更不想经历任何学习过程。
text_es: En los primeros 30 segundos usando un producto nuevo, eres flojo, vanidoso y egoísta. Quieres que todo salga súper rápido. Quieres quedar bien con tus colegas o amigos. Quieres sentirte exitoso de inmediato al usar este producto. No quieres tener que ver un tutorial ni leer nada, en realidad no quieres lidiar con ninguna curva de aprendizaje (learning curve).
context: Lenny asks Scott how he built his product sense and what advice he has for younger PMs. Scott explains his framework about the psychology of first-time users, describing what he calls the 'first mile' experience. He argues that understanding human psychology is crucial for product development, particularly recognizing that new users have very specific mental states and low tolerance for friction when they first encounter a product.
vocabulary_highlights: lazy, vain, and selfish, endure any learning curve whatsoever

speaker: Scott Belsky
speaker_expertise: Product Management, Company Building, Product Design
text: If you've lost conviction, you should not be doing what you're doing in the world of entrepreneurship. And I'll tell you, I get different answers. Some people are like, "Oh, Scott, I mean, I have more conviction. All that I've learned, all the validation I've received from customers, we just haven't figured it out yet. It's driving me crazy."
text_ko: 확신을 잃었다면, 기업가 정신의 세계에서 지금 하고 있는 일을 계속하면 안 돼요. 제가 여러 사람에게 물어보면, 반응이 다 달라요. 어떤 사람들은 "아, 스콧, 나는 더 확신이 있어요. 내가 배운 것들, 고객들한테 받은 검증들, 아직 해결하지 못한 것들 뿐이에요. 이게 나를 미치게 해요."라고 하더라고요.
text_zh: 如果你对自己做的事情没信心了，那你就不应该搞创业这一套。我跟你说，我得到的回答各种各样。有些人会说："哦，Scott，我的信心其实更足了。我学到的这些东西，客户给我的这些验证，我们只是还没找到门道而已。这事儿快把我逼疯了。"
text_es: Si has perdido la convicción, no deberías estar haciendo lo que estás haciendo en el mundo del emprendimiento. Y te digo, recibo respuestas muy diferentes. Algunas personas me dicen: "Ay, Scott, o sea, tengo más convicción que nunca. Todo lo que he aprendido, toda la validación que he recibido de los clientes, simplemente no hemos dado en el clavo todavía. Me tiene loco."
context: Lenny asks about Scott's advice on when founders should quit versus persevere through difficult times. Scott shares his framework for helping founders make this decision by asking them to evaluate their current conviction level compared to when they started. He explains that founders who maintain or increase conviction despite setbacks should continue, while those who have lost belief in their solution should consider pivoting or quitting entirely.
vocabulary_highlights: lost conviction, all the validation I've received, driving me crazy, just haven't figured it out yet

speaker: Scott Belsky
speaker_expertise: Product Management, Company Building, Product Design
text: I love bringing design upstream. In fact, that's probably been the cheat code of my career as a product leader, has just been disproportionately empowering design throughout the process.
text_ko: 저는 디자인을 초기 단계부터 참여시키는 걸 정말 좋아해요(bringing design upstream). 사실 제품 리더로서 제 커리어에서 그게 거의 치트 코드(cheat code)였어요 — 프로세스 전반에 걸쳐 디자인에 훨씬 더 많은 권한을 실어준 것이죠.
text_zh: 我特别喜欢把设计往前提，提到整个流程的上游去。说实话，这可能就是我作为产品负责人的一个秘诀吧，就是在整个过程中给设计更大的话语权，让它发挥更重要的作用。
text_es: Me encanta meter el diseño desde el principio del proceso. De hecho, esa ha sido probablemente la clave secreta de mi carrera como líder de producto: darle un peso desproporcionadamente grande al diseño en todo el proceso.
context: Lenny asks Scott about how he's helping PMs at Adobe leverage AI tools and new ways of working. Scott explains his approach to product development, emphasizing the importance of involving designers earlier in the product development process rather than just at the end for visual execution. He describes this as collapsing traditional organizational boundaries between product management and design functions.
vocabulary_highlights: bringing design upstream, cheat code, disproportionately empowering

speaker: Scott Belsky
speaker_expertise: Product Management, Company Building, Product Design
text: If resources are carbs, resourcefulness is like muscle. It stays with you. It makes you stronger, and it helps you have a better intuition and better performance over time. I've always found that resourcefulness brings you further than resources despite the fact that over the last seven to 10 years, we've basically thrown resources at every problem.
text_ko: 자원(resources)이 탄수화물이라면, 자원 활용력(resourcefulness)은 근육 같아요. 몸에 남아서 점점 더 강하게 해주고, 시간이 지날수록 직관력과 성과도 더 좋아지게 해줘요. 지난 7~10년 동안 사실상 모든 문제에 자원을 쏟아부었지만, 저는 항상 자원 활용력(resourcefulness)이 자원(resources)보다 더 멀리 데려다준다는 걸 느껴왔어요.
text_zh: 如果说资源就像碳水化合物的话，那么机智应变(resourcefulness)就像肌肉一样。它会一直跟着你，让你变得更强，时间长了你的直觉会更准，表现也会更好。我一直觉得机智应变比光有资源更能让你走得远，虽然这七八年来，我们基本上遇到什么问题都是拿资源砸。
text_es: Si los recursos son como los carbohidratos, el ingenio es como el músculo. Se queda contigo. Te hace más fuerte y te ayuda a desarrollar mejor intuición y mejor rendimiento con el tiempo. Siempre he visto que el ingenio te lleva más lejos que los recursos, a pesar de que en los últimos siete a diez años básicamente hemos estado tirando recursos a cada problema que surge.
context: Scott shares his final words of wisdom for product builders, focusing on the current economic environment where companies have fewer resources. He contrasts the recent trend of solving problems by throwing money and headcount at them versus being forced to find more creative, efficient solutions. Scott argues this resource-constrained environment actually creates opportunities for teams to develop stronger problem-solving capabilities.
vocabulary_highlights: resourcefulness brings you further than resources, thrown resources at every problem

speaker: Scott Belsky
speaker_expertise: Product Management, Company Building, Product Design
text: Creative professionals can now explore 10X the surface area of possibility. These tools are making them so much more efficient. And some people are like, "Oh my gosh, creative pros are going to be replaced." No. No, no, no. They're not. They're just going to find 10X better solutions.
text_ko: 크리에이티브 전문가들은 이제 탐색할 수 있는 가능성의 폭을 10배(10X)로 넓혀볼 수 있어요. 이런 도구들 덕분에 훨씬 더 효율적으로 일하게 됐고요. 그러면 어떤 사람들은 "오 마이 갓, 창의 전문가들이 대체되는 거 아니야?"라고 말해요. 아니에요. 전혀 아니에요. 그들은 사라지는 게 아니라, 단지 10배 더 나은 해결책을 찾아내게 될 거예요.
text_zh: 现在创意工作者能探索的可能性比以前多了十倍。这些工具让他们的效率大大提升。有些人就说"哎呀，创意专业人士要被取代了"。不对，完全不是这么回事。他们不会被取代，只是能找到比现在好十倍的解决方案。
text_es: Los profesionales creativos ahora pueden explorar diez veces más posibilidades. Estas herramientas los están haciendo muchísimo más eficientes. Y hay gente que dice: "Ay, Dios mío, van a reemplazar a los creativos". No. No, no, no. Para nada. Lo que van a hacer es encontrar soluciones diez veces mejores.
context: Lenny asks Scott to talk about what Adobe is working on and Scott explains three waves of transformation driving Adobe's strategy. One key wave is how AI tools are empowering creative professionals rather than replacing them. Scott argues that generative AI allows designers and creatives to explore far more possibilities in the same amount of time, leading to better creative solutions rather than job displacement.
vocabulary_highlights: 10X the surface area of possibility, creative pros, 10X better solutions

speaker: Scott Wu
speaker_expertise: AI/ML Products, Product Management, Team Building
text: Our whole team is only like 15 engineers a year. We use a ton of Devin when we're building Devin. Most folks on the team are definitely working with up to five Devins at once, and so Devin merges like several hundred pull requests into production in the Devin code bases every month.
text_ko: 우리 팀 전체는 한 해에 대략 엔지니어 15명 정도밖에 안 돼요. Devin을 만들 때 우리는 Devin을 진짜 많이 활용해요. 팀원 대부분은 한 번에 최대 다섯 개의 Devin을 다루고 있고, 그래서 Devin은 매달 코드베이스(code bases)에 수백 건의 풀 리퀘스트(pull requests)를 프로덕션(production)으로 머지(merge)해요.
text_zh: 我们整个团队一年也就15个工程师左右。我们在开发Devin的时候大量使用Devin本身。团队里大部分人都是同时和最多5个Devin一起干活，所以每个月Devin都会往生产环境合并几百个pull request到Devin的代码库里。
text_es: Nuestro equipo completo son como 15 ingenieros al año nada más. Usamos Devin un montón cuando estamos desarrollando Devin. La mayoría del equipo definitivamente está trabajando con hasta cinco Devins a la vez, y entonces Devin fusiona como varios cientos de pull requests a producción en las bases de código de Devin cada mes.
context: Lenny is asking Scott about how Cognition, the company that builds Devin, uses their own AI engineer internally. Scott explains how their small engineering team of 15 people leverages multiple Devin instances to accelerate their development process. This demonstrates the practical application of AI engineers in a real production environment, where each human engineer manages multiple AI assistants simultaneously.
vocabulary_highlights: a ton of, definitely working with, pull requests

speaker: Scott Wu
speaker_expertise: AI/ML Products, Product Management, Team Building
text: AI is going to be the biggest technology shift of our lives, so most of the big tech revolutions that we've had over the last 50 years, like personal computer, and the internet, and the mobile phone, they all had this big hardware component that was a big part of the distribution. One of the things which is already I'd say different in AI, is just how explosive the technology can be. There's no weight on hardware distribution.
text_ko: 인공지능(AI)은 우리 삶에서 겪게 될 가장 큰 기술적 전환일 거예요. 지난 50년 동안 있었던 큰 기술 혁명들—개인용 컴퓨터(personal computer), 인터넷(internet), 휴대전화(mobile phone)—은 모두 유통에서 큰 비중을 차지한 하드웨어 요소가 있었어요. 그런데 인공지능(AI)은 이미 다른 점이 하나 있어요: 기술 자체가 얼마나 폭발적으로 확산될 수 있는지예요. 하드웨어 유통(hardware distribution)에 얽매여 있지 않거든요.
text_zh: AI会是我们这辈子遇到的最大的技术变革。你看过去50年那些重大的科技革命，比如个人电脑、互联网、手机，它们都有一个共同点，就是硬件是很重要的一块，硬件的普及决定了技术能推广到什么程度。但AI这次不一样，我觉得最明显的区别就是这技术爆发力太强了，完全不受硬件分发的限制。
text_es: La IA va a ser el cambio tecnológico más grande de nuestras vidas. Fíjate que todas las grandes revoluciones tecnológicas que hemos tenido en los últimos 50 años - como la computadora personal, el internet, el celular - todas tenían ese componente de hardware que era clave para su distribución. Pero algo que ya veo diferente con la IA es lo explosivo que puede ser esta tecnología. No depende para nada de la distribución de hardware.
context: Lenny asks Scott about the future impact of AI technology. Scott compares AI to previous major technological shifts like personal computers, the internet, and mobile phones, explaining why AI adoption could be more rapid. Unlike previous technologies that required physical hardware distribution limiting their spread, AI can scale instantly without hardware constraints, making its growth potentially more explosive than past innovations.
vocabulary_highlights: biggest technology shift, explosive, weight on hardware distribution

speaker: Scott Wu
speaker_expertise: AI/ML Products, Product Management, Team Building
text: I think there's going to be way more programmers and way more engineers a few years from now. Pretty quickly. The form factor of what it means to be a programmer obviously is going to change, but at the end of the day, of course the discipline is all about just being able to tell your computer what's do. And so in that lens, I really think that programming is only going to become more and more important as AI gets more powerful.
text_ko: 제 생각에는 앞으로 몇 년 안에 프로그래머(programmer)랑 엔지니어(engineer)가 훨씬 더 많아질 거예요. 꽤 빠르게요. 프로그래머라는 개념의 형태(form factor)는 분명히 바뀔 텐데, 결국 이 분야는 컴퓨터(computer)에게 무엇을 하라고 지시할 수 있는 능력에 관한 거예요. 그런 관점에서 보면 인공지능(AI)이 더 강력해질수록 프로그래밍(programming)은 점점 더 중요해질 거라고 정말 생각해요.
text_zh: 我觉得再过几年，程序员和工程师的数量会大幅增加，而且会很快。当程序员的形式肯定会变，但说到底，这个行业本质上就是要能告诉电脑该做什么。从这个角度看，我真的认为随着AI越来越强大，编程只会变得越来越重要。
text_es: Creo que va a haber muchísimos más programadores e ingenieros en unos años. Bastante rápido, la verdad. Obviamente va a cambiar completamente lo que significa ser programador, pero al final del día, claro, la disciplina se trata simplemente de poder decirle a tu computadora qué tiene que hacer. Y desde esa perspectiva, realmente creo que la programación va a ser cada vez más importante mientras la IA se vuelve más poderosa.
context: Lenny asks how the role of being an engineer and building software is changing. Scott argues against the common fear that AI will reduce the need for programmers. Instead, he believes AI will actually increase demand for engineers by making programming more accessible and powerful. He emphasizes that programming fundamentally remains about instructing computers what to do, which becomes more valuable as AI capabilities expand.
vocabulary_highlights: form factor, at the end of the day, in that lens

speaker: Scott Wu
speaker_expertise: AI/ML Products, Product Management, Team Building
text: And then the other thing that we felt very strongly about was that the product experience was going to shift from what I'll call text completion to agents basically. The big shift that we really felt we would see is moving from kind of this text to text model to an actual autonomous system that can make decisions, that can interact with the real world, that can take in feedback, that can iterate and take multiple steps to solve problems.
text_ko: 그리고 우리가 특히 확신했던 또 하나는 제품 경험이 제가 '텍스트 완성(text completion)'이라고 부르는 것에서 기본적으로 '에이전트(agents)'로 전환될 거라는 점이에요. 우리가 정말로 예상한 큰 변화는 일종의 텍스트-투-텍스트 모델(text-to-text model)에서 벗어나 스스로 결정을 내리고 현실 세계와 상호작용하며 피드백(feedback)을 받아들여 반복(iterate)하고 여러 단계를 거쳐 문제를 해결할 수 있는 실제 자율 시스템(autonomous system)으로 옮겨간다는 거예요.
text_zh: 然后还有一点我们特别坚信的就是，产品体验会从我说的文本补全转向智能体(agents)。我们真正感受到的大变化是，从这种文本到文本的模式转向真正的自主系统，这个系统能做决策，能跟现实世界交互，能接收反馈，能不断迭代，还能通过多个步骤来解决问题。
text_es: Y después, lo otro en lo que teníamos clarísimo es que la experiencia del producto iba a cambiar de lo que yo llamaría completar texto a básicamente agentes. El gran cambio que realmente veíamos venir era pasar de este modelo de texto a texto a un sistema autónomo de verdad que puede tomar decisiones, que puede interactuar con el mundo real, que puede recibir feedback, que puede iterar y dar varios pasos para resolver problemas.
context: Scott is explaining Cognition's founding thesis and why they chose to focus on autonomous coding agents rather than simpler AI coding tools. He describes their early belief that AI would evolve beyond basic text completion (like GitHub Copilot) toward fully autonomous systems. This represents a fundamental shift from AI tools that assist with writing code to AI systems that can independently complete entire software engineering tasks.
vocabulary_highlights: felt very strongly about, text to text model, take multiple steps

speaker: Scott Wu
speaker_expertise: AI/ML Products, Product Management, Team Building
text: I think there are certain things that it is much better at than a human. There are certain things that it's much worse at than a human. And I think over the last year we've learned a lot especially about not just coding agents but agents in general just really building out how all of us should be working and interacting with agents as part of our flow.
text_ko: 저는 어떤 일들은 사람보다 훨씬 잘하는 부분이 분명히 있다고 생각해요. 반대로 어떤 일들은 사람보다 훨씬 못하는 부분도 있어요. 그리고 지난 1년 동안 우리는 특히 코딩 에이전트(coding agents)뿐만 아니라 에이전트(agents) 전반에 대해, 에이전트를 우리의 워크플로(workflow)의 일부로서 어떻게 함께 일하고 상호작용하게 할지에 대해 많은 걸 배웠어요.
text_zh: 我觉得AI在某些方面确实比人强很多，但在另一些方面又比人差得远。这一年下来我们学到了不少东西，特别是不光是代码智能体(coding agents)，而是各种智能体(agents)，就是怎么把这些智能体融入到我们的工作流程里，大家该怎么跟它们配合。
text_es: Creo que hay ciertas cosas en las que es mucho mejor que los humanos. Hay otras en las que es mucho peor que nosotros. Y creo que durante el último año hemos aprendido muchísimo, especialmente no solo sobre los agentes de programación sino sobre los agentes en general, realmente desarrollando cómo todos nosotros deberíamos trabajar e interactuar con los agentes como parte de nuestro flujo de trabajo.
context: Lenny asks Scott to compare Devin's current capabilities to human engineers using a seniority framework. Scott introduces the concept of 'jagged intelligence' - the idea that AI systems have very uneven capabilities, excelling dramatically in some areas while performing poorly in others. He explains that much of their learning has focused not just on improving Devin's coding abilities, but on figuring out optimal human-AI collaboration workflows.
vocabulary_highlights: much better at, much worse at, as part of our flow

speaker: Scott Wu
speaker_expertise: AI/ML Products, Product Management, Team Building
text: I think the way that we've always thought about it is there's layers of abstraction and there's tools, and one way I would say it at a high level is kind of I think of AI in general as, yeah, I mean computers are obviously getting more and more intelligence and are able to do more and more and it's possible there may come a day where computers truly do everything that we do and humans are not responsible for any of it.
text_ko: 제가 보기에 우리가 늘 그렇게 생각해온 방식은 추상화 계층(layers of abstraction)과 여러 도구들이 있다는 거예요. 한마디로 말하면, 인공지능(AI)을 대체로 이렇게 생각해요. 그러니까 컴퓨터가 점점 더 지능을 갖추고 할 수 있는 일이 늘어나고 있고, 어쩌면 언젠가는 컴퓨터가 우리가 하는 모든 일을 진짜로 다 해내서 인간은 아무런 책임도 지지 않는 날이 올 수도 있다고 생각해요.
text_zh: 我觉得我们一直以来的想法就是，技术有很多层级，也有各种工具，从宏观角度来说，我对AI的理解就是，电脑明显是越来越聪明了，能干的事也越来越多，说不定哪天电脑真的能把我们人类做的所有事都包了，到时候可能就不需要人来负责任何事情了。
text_es: Mira, yo creo que siempre lo hemos visto así: hay diferentes niveles de abstracción (layers of abstraction) y hay herramientas, y si lo digo a grandes rasgos, pienso en la IA en general como... bueno, es obvio que las computadoras cada vez son más inteligentes y pueden hacer más y más cosas, y es posible que llegue el día en que las computadoras realmente hagan todo lo que hacemos nosotros y los humanos ya no seamos responsables de nada.
context: Lenny asks Scott how the act of being an engineer is changing for companies using Devin today. Scott provides his philosophical perspective on AI's role in programming, emphasizing that software engineering has always been about instructing computers through layers of abstraction. He acknowledges the possibility of full automation while focusing on the current reality where humans remain essential to the programming process.
vocabulary_highlights: layers of abstraction, at a high level, are not responsible for any of it

speaker: Scott Wu
speaker_expertise: AI/ML Products, Product Management, Team Building
text: One of the ways that we've kind of thought about Devin in building Devin is really allowing engineers to go from bricklayer to architect, so to speak. A lot of it is just getting to the point where you can do the high-level directing and you can basically specify things exactly how you want. I think it's very much about still having the human in control and having the human able to do the full specification, but just multiplying the magnitude of what you can do and what you can build in one day or one hour or however long.
text_ko: 우리가 Devin을 만들면서 생각한 것 중 하나는 엔지니어들이 벽돌공에서 건축가로 역할을 전환할 수 있게 해주는 거예요. 많은 부분이 결국 상위 수준의 지시(high-level directing)를 할 수 있는 단계에 이르고, 원하는 대로 정확히 지정(specify)할 수 있게 되는 거죠. 핵심은 여전히 사람이 주도권을 가지고 전체 사양(full specification)을 직접 작성할 수 있다는 점이고, 다만 하루나 한 시간 같은 짧은 시간 안에 할 수 있는 일과 만들 수 있는 것들의 규모를 훨씬 더 키워준다는 거예요.
text_zh: 我们在开发Devin的时候，有个想法就是让工程师能够从搬砖工变成架构师，这么说吧。很大程度上就是让你能够做高层次的指导工作，基本上可以完全按照你想要的方式去指定需求。我觉得这还是要让人来掌控全局，让人能够做完整的需求规划，只不过是把你一天或者一小时内能完成的工作量和能搭建的东西成倍放大。
text_es: Una de las formas en que hemos pensado en Devin al desarrollarlo es realmente permitir que los ingenieros pasen de ser albañiles a ser arquitectos, por decirlo así. Mucho de esto se trata de llegar al punto donde puedes hacer la dirección de alto nivel y básicamente especificar las cosas exactamente como las quieres. Creo que se trata mucho de seguir teniendo al humano en control y que el humano pueda hacer toda la especificación, pero simplemente multiplicar la magnitud de lo que puedes hacer y lo que puedes construir en un día o en una hora o el tiempo que sea.
context: Scott is describing how Devin changes the role of software engineers by handling routine implementation tasks. The 'bricklayer to architect' metaphor illustrates how engineers can shift from hands-on coding work to high-level design and specification. Scott emphasizes that humans remain in control of decision-making and architectural choices while AI handles the detailed implementation work, effectively multiplying human productivity.
vocabulary_highlights: so to speak, high-level directing, multiplying the magnitude

speaker: Sean Ellis
text: When I go in and directly am involved with a company on the acquisition side, I am thinking about my hypotheses on the acquisition pretty early on, because if I go into it and I have no idea how we'll acquire those customers, I'm not real confident I'll figure it out when I'm there.
text_ko: 제가 직접 고객 확보(acquisition) 쪽으로 회사에 들어가서 관여할 때는, 고객 확보에 대한 가설을 꽤 일찍부터 세워요. 왜냐하면 들어가서 그 고객들을 어떻게 확보할지 전혀 감이 없다면, 현장에서 가서 그걸 알아낼 수 있을 거라는 확신이 별로 안 들거든요.
text_zh: 当我直接参与一家公司的收购时，我会很早就开始思考我对这次收购的假设，因为如果我进去的时候对怎么获取那些客户一点头绪都没有，我可不敢保证到时候能想出办法来。
text_es: Cuando me meto de lleno y me involucro directamente con una empresa en el tema de adquisición, desde muy temprano ya estoy pensando en mis hipótesis sobre cómo vamos a captar clientes, porque si entro sin tener ni idea de cómo vamos a conseguir esos clientes, la verdad es que no me da mucha confianza que lo vaya a resolver una vez que ya esté ahí metido.
context: Lenny asks Sean about his approach to helping companies figure out growth strategy. Sean explains that even though he focuses on activation and onboarding first, he still develops early hypotheses about customer acquisition channels before taking on a project. He wants to have 2-3 viable acquisition ideas going in, knowing he'll likely discover more, so that at least one channel will work profitably.
vocabulary_highlights: hypotheses on the acquisition, real confident, figure it out

speaker: Sean Ellis
text: Customer acquisition is so hard that if you're not really efficient at converting and retaining and monetizing people, you're going to really struggle on the customer acquisition side.
text_ko: 고객 획득(customer acquisition)이 워낙 힘들어서, 전환(converting)·유지(retaining)·수익화(monetizing)을 효율적으로 못하면 고객 확보 쪽에서 진짜 고생해요.
text_zh: 获客这么难，如果你在转化、留存和变现这块做得不够好的话，那获客这边你肯定会很吃力。
text_es: Conseguir clientes nuevos es tan difícil que si no eres realmente eficiente convirtiendo, reteniendo y monetizando a la gente, te va a costar muchísimo en el lado de adquisición de clientes.
context: Sean explains his prioritization approach to growth - focusing first on activation, then engagement and referrals, then revenue optimization, and only lastly on customer acquisition. He argues that in today's competitive environment, companies must be extremely efficient at converting, retaining, and monetizing customers before they can succeed at scalable customer acquisition.
vocabulary_highlights: really struggle on, monetizing people

speaker: Sean Ellis
text: If you start paying attention to what your somewhat disappointed users are telling you and then you start tweaking onboarding and product based on their feedback, maybe you're going to dilute it for your must have users.
text_ko: 다소 실망한 사용자들이 하는 말에 귀 기울여 그 피드백을 바탕으로 온보딩(onboarding)과 제품을 조금씩 손봐서 맞추기 시작하면, 오히려 핵심 사용자들(must-have users)에게는 제품의 강점이 희석될 수 있어요.
text_zh: 如果你开始关注那些有点失望的用户的反馈，然后根据他们的意见去调整用户引导(onboarding)和产品，可能会让你的核心用户体验变差。
text_es: Si empiezas a hacerle caso a lo que te dicen los usuarios que están medio decepcionados y luego te pones a ajustar el onboarding y el producto basándote en sus comentarios, a lo mejor vas a terminar diluyendo la experiencia para tus usuarios que realmente no pueden vivir sin tu producto.
context: Lenny asks what to do when only 10% of users would be very disappointed without the product. Sean advises ignoring users who say they'd be 'somewhat disappointed' because they view the product as nice-to-have. He warns that optimizing for these users might make the product good for everyone but great for no one, potentially weakening its value for the core must-have users.
vocabulary_highlights: paying attention to, tweaking onboarding, dilute it for

speaker: Sean Ellis
text: I think one of the biggest challenges in an early stage startup is half the people feel like we're years from having this product ready to grow, and half the people are like, 'What are we waiting for?' Where if you can actually get people on the same page of what does product market fit look like for our business, and it's at that point that we're going to.
text_ko: 제 생각에 초창기 스타트업(early stage startup)에서 가장 큰 문제 중 하나는 팀의 절반은 '이 제품이 성장할 준비가 되려면 몇 년은 더 걸리겠구나'라고 느끼고, 나머지 절반은 '우린 도대체 뭘 기다리고 있는 거야?'라고 생각하는 거예요. 그런데 제품-시장 적합성(product market fit)이 우리 비즈니스에서 어떤 모습이어야 하는지 모두가 같은 페이지에 있으면, 바로 그때부터 움직이기 시작하는 거죠.
text_zh: 我觉得早期创业公司最大的挑战之一就是，一半的人觉得我们的产品离能够规模化还有好几年，另一半的人就说"我们还在等什么？"这时候如果你能让大家对什么叫产品市场契合度(product market fit)达成共识，明确到了那个点我们就要开始行动。
text_es: Creo que uno de los mayores retos en una startup que está empezando es que la mitad del equipo siente que nos faltan años para tener el producto listo para crecer, y la otra mitad está como "¿qué estamos esperando?" Entonces, si logras que toda la gente esté en la misma página sobre cómo se ve el product market fit para nuestro negocio, ahí es cuando vamos a...
context: Lenny asks about how firm the 40% threshold is in the Sean Ellis test. Sean explains that having a specific target like 40% helps align teams on when to start scaling growth efforts. Without this alignment, startup teams often split between those who think the product needs years more work and those eager to start growing immediately.
vocabulary_highlights: get people on the same page, what are we waiting for
topics: Leadership & Management, Decision Making, Starting a Company

speaker: Sean Ellis
text: Even when I first moved to Silicon Valley, I remember the conversations back at LogMeIn in the mid 2000s of kind of like, 'When do we step on the gas? What is the combination of factors that need to be in place before we start pouring fuel on the early fire?'
text_ko: 실리콘밸리(Silicon Valley)로 처음 왔을 때도, 2000년대 중반 LogMeIn에서 나눴던 대화가 기억나요. 대충 이런 얘기였어요: "언제 엑셀을 밟아야 할까요? 초기 불씨에 연료를 더 붓기 전에 어떤 요소들이 갖춰져야 할까요?"
text_zh: 我记得2000年代中期刚到硅谷的时候，我们在LogMeIn内部经常讨论这样的问题："什么时候该全力冲刺？需要哪些条件都到位了，我们才能开始给这个刚起步的项目大力投入资源？"
text_es: Incluso cuando me mudé por primera vez a Silicon Valley, recuerdo las conversaciones que teníamos en LogMeIn a mediados de los 2000, algo así como: '¿Cuándo le metemos el acelerador a fondo? ¿Qué combinación de factores tiene que estar en su lugar antes de echarle más leña al fuego inicial?'
context: Sean continues explaining why having a clear product-market fit threshold is important for startup teams. He shares how even before the term 'product-market fit' existed, his team at LogMeIn in the mid-2000s struggled with the same fundamental question of when exactly to start aggressively scaling their growth efforts.
vocabulary_highlights: step on the gas, pouring fuel on the early fire
topics: Starting a Company, Decision Making, Growth & Marketing

speaker: Sean Ellis
text: I think basically for each business it's just thinking about what's unique for that business that is going to open up channel opportunities and everyone's going to be a little bit, I think jaded from whatever the last thing that worked really well.
text_ko: 제 생각엔 기본적으로 각 비즈니스는 자기만의 고유한 게 뭔지 생각해서 그걸로 채널 기회(channel opportunities)를 만들어내는 게 중요해요. 그리고 사람들은 이전에 효과가 좋았던 것 때문에 다들 좀 식상해져 있을 거예요.
text_zh: 我觉得基本上每个生意都要想想，自己有什么独特的地方能开拓新的渠道机会，而且大家对之前那些很成功的做法多少都会有点审美疲劳。
text_es: Mira, creo que básicamente para cada negocio se trata de pensar qué es lo único de ese negocio que va a abrir oportunidades de canal, y todo el mundo va a estar un poco escamado por lo último que funcionó realmente bien.
context: Lenny asks how to help businesses figure out which growth channel to focus on - whether paid acquisition, SEO, sales, or virality. Sean explains that each business has unique characteristics that make certain channels more viable, and warns that people often get biased by their previous successful experiences and try to apply the same approach to different businesses.
vocabulary_highlights: open up channel opportunities, jaded from whatever, worked really well

speaker: Seth Godin
text: Well, the first question is what's a brand? Because it's not a logo. A brand is a promise. It's what do I expect from you. It's would I miss you if you were gone. And Hyatt Hotels has a logo, Nike has a brand. The way we know this is if Nike opened a hotel, we'd know what it would be like.
text_ko: 첫 번째 질문은 '브랜드가 뭐예요?'예요. 왜냐하면 브랜드는 로고(logo)가 아니거든요. 브랜드(brand)는 약속이에요. 그 브랜드에게서 무엇을 기대하느냐는 거예요. 그 브랜드가 사라지면 그리울까 하는 거죠. 하얏트 호텔(Hyatt Hotels)은 로고(logo)가 있고, 나이키(Nike)는 브랜드(brand)가 있어요. 우리가 이걸 아는 방법은, 만약 나이키가 호텔을 연다면 어떤 느낌일지 알 수 있기 때문이에요.
text_zh: 首先，什么叫品牌？品牌可不是一个标志那么简单。品牌其实是一种承诺，就是我对你的期待是什么，你要是没了我会不会想念你。凯悦酒店有的只是个标志，但耐克有的是品牌。怎么证明呢？如果耐克开酒店，我们马上就能想象出那会是什么样子。
text_es: Bueno, la primera pregunta es ¿qué es una marca? Porque no es un logo. Una marca es una promesa. Es qué espero de ti. Es si te echaría de menos si desaparecieras. Y Hyatt Hotels tiene un logo, Nike tiene una marca. Y sabemos esto porque si Nike abriera un hotel, sabríamos exactamente cómo sería.
context: Lenny asks Seth how new AI companies can build brands to distinguish themselves in an increasingly crowded market. Seth first clarifies what a brand actually is - not a logo, but a promise and set of expectations. He explains that true brands transcend product categories because people understand what the brand stands for, using Nike as an example of a strong brand versus Hyatt as just a logo.
vocabulary_highlights: transcend product categories, what's in this for the user

speaker: Seth Godin
text: AI very soon is going to stop being a feature the same way electricity is not a feature. What AI companies and all companies need to do is say, what's in this for the user? What promise do I want to make a difficult promise, a remarkable promise, and then how do I keep it?
text_ko: 머지않아 인공지능(AI)은 전기(electricity)처럼 더 이상 '기능(feature)'으로 여겨지지 않을 거예요. AI 회사든 모든 회사든 스스로에게 물어봐야 할 건 '이게 사용자에게 어떤 가치가 있지?'예요. 내가 어떤 약속을 하고 싶은가요? 어렵지만 의미 있는, 눈에 띄는 약속을 정하고 그 약속을 어떻게 지킬지 고민해야 해요.
text_zh: AI很快就不会再是一个功能特色了，就像电力一样——你不会说电力是个特色功能对吧？AI公司也好，其他公司也好，都得想清楚一个问题：用户能从中得到什么好处？我要给用户一个什么样的承诺？这个承诺得有挑战性，得让人眼前一亮，然后最关键的是——我怎么兑现这个承诺？
text_es: Muy pronto la IA va a dejar de ser una funcionalidad, igual que la electricidad ya no es una funcionalidad. Lo que las empresas de IA y todas las empresas tienen que preguntarse es: ¿qué gana el usuario con esto? ¿Qué promesa quiero hacer - una promesa difícil, una promesa que realmente marque la diferencia - y entonces cómo la voy a cumplir?
context: Following up on his brand definition, Seth addresses how AI companies specifically should approach branding. He predicts that AI will become ubiquitous infrastructure rather than a differentiating feature, similar to how electricity powers many products but isn't considered special. He emphasizes that companies should focus on making and keeping meaningful promises to users rather than promoting their use of AI technology.
vocabulary_highlights: stop being a feature, remarkable promise

speaker: Seth Godin
text: I define good taste as knowing what other people want just before they do. So if you're the only person who wants peanut butter covered licorice, you're entitled to eat peanut butter covered licorice, but you don't have good taste because everyone else thinks that's weird.
text_ko: 저는 좋은 취향을 '다른 사람들이 원하기 직전에 그들이 뭘 원하는지 알아내는 능력'이라고 정의해요. 그러니까 만약 당신 혼자만 땅콩버터를 바른 리코리스를 좋아한다면, 그걸 먹을 권리는 있어요. 다만 그건 좋은 취향이라고 보긴 어려워요 — 다른 사람들은 그걸 이상하게 생각하니까요.
text_zh: 我觉得品味好就是能比别人早一步知道他们想要什么。比如说，如果全世界就你一个人想吃花生酱裹甘草糖，那你当然可以吃，但这不叫有品味，因为别人都觉得这太奇怪了。
text_es: Yo defino el buen gusto como saber lo que otros quieren justo antes de que ellos se den cuenta. O sea, si eres la única persona que quiere regaliz cubierto de mantequilla de maní, perfecto, tienes todo el derecho de comértelo, pero no tienes buen gusto porque todos los demás piensan que eso está rarísimo.
context: Lenny asks Seth how to recognize and develop good taste and high standards, based on advice from Wes Kao who worked with Seth. Seth provides his definition of good taste - the ability to anticipate what others will want before they realize it themselves. He uses a humorous food example to illustrate that personal preference alone doesn't constitute good taste; it must resonate with others.
vocabulary_highlights: just before they do, you're entitled to

speaker: Seth Godin
text: Standards, it's worth understanding what quality is and the people who listen to this podcast know better than most. Quality is not luxury. Quality is not perfection. Quality means meeting spec, and if you meet spec, you're done. If you don't think the spec is good enough, make a better spec.
text_ko: 기준(standards) 얘기인데요, 품질이 무엇인지 제대로 이해하는 게 중요해요. 이 팟캐스트를 들으시는 분들은 대부분 그걸 더 잘 아세요. 품질은 사치가 아니고, 품질은 완벽함도 아니에요. 품질이란 스펙(spec)을 충족시키는 거예요. 스펙을 충족하면 그걸로 끝이에요. 스펙이 충분히 좋지 않다고 생각되면 더 나은 스펙을 만드세요.
text_zh: 说到标准，咱们得先搞清楚什么是质量，听这个播客的人比大部分人都更懂这个道理。质量不等于奢华，也不等于完美。质量就是达到规格要求，只要你达标了，就算完成任务了。如果你觉得现有的规格标准不够好，那就制定一个更好的标准。
text_es: Mira, hablando de estándares, vale la pena entender qué es realmente la calidad, y la gente que escucha este podcast lo sabe mejor que nadie. La calidad no es lujo. La calidad no es perfección. Calidad significa cumplir con las especificaciones, y si cumples con las especificaciones, ya está, listo. Si crees que las especificaciones no son lo suficientemente buenas, pues haz mejores especificaciones.
context: Continuing the discussion about building high standards, Seth clarifies what quality actually means in product development. He argues that quality isn't about luxury or perfectionism, but about clearly defining specifications and meeting them consistently. His advice is that if you're unsatisfied with the current standard, improve the specification rather than endlessly tweaking a product that already meets requirements.
vocabulary_highlights: meeting spec, make a better spec

speaker: Seth Godin
text: Tension is at the heart of every art form and every innovation. What we do when we launch a new product, we say, we have this thing that can do X, and now the person is imagining what their life might be like if that were true. If they fall in love with that possibility, now there's tension. Did you tell the truth? Is it going to work for them?
text_ko: 긴장감은 모든 예술과 모든 혁신의 핵심이에요. 신제품을 출시할 때(launch) 우리가 하는 건 “이게 X를 할 수 있다”라고 말하는 거고, 그러면 사람들은 그게 사실이라면 자신의 삶이 어떻게 달라질지 상상해요. 그 가능성에 마음이 끌리면 긴장감이 생겨요. 진실을 말했나요? 그게 그들에게 통할까요?
text_zh: 张力是所有艺术形式和创新的核心。我们推出新产品的时候，其实就是在说，我们有个东西能做到X，然后用户就开始想象，要是真能这样，我的生活会变成什么样。如果他们爱上了这种可能性，张力就产生了。你说的是真话吗？这个产品对他们来说真的有用吗？
text_es: La tensión está en el corazón de cualquier forma de arte y de toda innovación. Lo que hacemos cuando lanzamos un producto nuevo es decir: "Tenemos esto que puede hacer X", y entonces la persona se imagina cómo podría ser su vida si eso fuera cierto. Si se enamoran de esa posibilidad, ahí surge la tensión. ¿Les dijiste la verdad? ¿Realmente les va a funcionar?
context: Lenny asks Seth about a key concept from his new book - why great strategies need tension at their center. Seth distinguishes between harmful stress and productive tension, explaining that tension drives creativity and innovation. He describes how product launches create tension by making promises that cause customers to imagine better futures, creating suspense about whether the product will actually deliver on those promises.
vocabulary_highlights: fall in love with that possibility

speaker: Seth Godin
text: When you choose your smallest viable audience, what language they speak, how much money they have, what problem they're trying to solve, what their technical facility is, whether they're short-tempered, whether they're kind, whether they're going to stick with you, you have chosen everything that's going to go into the product and what your future is going to be like.
text_ko: 당신이 최소 유효 고객층 (smallest viable audience)을 정할 때, 그들이 어떤 언어를 쓰는지, 재정 상태가 어떤지, 어떤 문제를 해결하려 하는지, 기술 숙련도 (technical facility)는 어떤지, 성미가 급한지, 친절한지, 당신과 계속 함께해줄 사람들인지까지 모두 선택하는 거예요. 그 선택들이 결국 제품에 들어갈 모든 것과 당신의 미래를 결정해요.
text_zh: 你选择最小可行受众(smallest viable audience)的时候，比如他们说什么语言、有多少钱、想解决什么问题、技术水平怎么样、是不是急性子、人品好不好、会不会跟你走到底，这些其实就已经决定了你的产品会做成什么样，你的未来会是什么样子。
text_es: Cuando defines tu audiencia mínima viable (smallest viable audience), qué idioma hablan, cuánto dinero manejan, qué problema están tratando de resolver, qué tan buenos son con la tecnología, si son impacientes o pacientes, si son buena onda, si van a quedarse contigo a largo plazo, básicamente ya decidiste todo lo que va a tener tu producto y cómo va a ser tu futuro.
context: Lenny asks Seth about four critical strategic choices from his book that determine a product's future. Seth explains the first choice - selecting your customers - and argues that this decision shapes everything else about your product and business. He emphasizes that by defining your target audience's characteristics, constraints, and behaviors, you're essentially determining your product requirements and company trajectory.
vocabulary_highlights: smallest viable audience, technical facility, short-tempered

speaker: Seth Godin
text: The word remarkable means worth making a remark about. So I'm not talking about coming up with some viral video that's ridiculous in its gimmickry. I'm saying if you make something where the person's life gets better if they talk about you and you know in advance what you want them to say, then they are more likely to say it.
text_ko: remarkable이라는 단어는 ‘말할 만한 가치가 있다’는 뜻이에요. 그러니까 제가 말하는 건 기교만 요란한 바이럴 영상(viral video)을 하나 만들어 유행시키자는 얘기가 아니에요. 제 말은, 누군가가 당신에 대해 이야기하면 그 사람의 삶이 실제로 더 나아지고, 그리고 당신이 미리 그들이 어떤 얘기를 하길 원하는지 알고 있다면 그들이 그 말을 할 가능성이 더 높아진다는 거예요.
text_zh: "Remarkable"这个词的意思就是值得别人去聊、去说的。所以我说的不是搞那种靠噱头博眼球的病毒视频。我的意思是，如果你做的东西能让别人通过谈论你而受益，而且你提前就想好了希望他们说什么，那他们就更愿意主动去说。
text_es: La palabra "remarkable" significa que vale la pena comentar algo. Así que no estoy hablando de crear algún video viral ridículo lleno de trucos baratos. Lo que digo es que si haces algo donde la vida de la persona mejora cuando habla de ti, y además sabes de antemano qué quieres que digan, entonces es mucho más probable que lo digan.
context: Lenny asks Seth to explain his famous Purple Cow concept about being remarkable. Seth clarifies that being remarkable isn't about creating viral gimmicks, but about building products that people genuinely want to recommend to others. He emphasizes that remarkable products make customers' lives better when they share them, and successful companies should anticipate what customers will say about their products.
vocabulary_highlights: worth making a remark about, ridiculous in its gimmickry, in advance

speaker: Shaun Clowes
text: Why is it that product management is still such a relatively undeveloped discipline? We're like 15 to 20 years into this, and so there's something about the current state of product management that isn't getting at the truly important things, the truly value-added things. If we were doctors, you'd be like, "That's totally unacceptable."
text_ko: 프로덕트 매니지먼트(product management)가 왜 아직도 상대적으로 덜 발달한 분야일까요? 이제 한 15~20년 정도 지났는데도, 현재의 프로덕트 매니지먼트는 진짜로 중요한 것들, 실제로 부가가치(value-added)를 만들어내는 부분에 제대로 닿지 못하고 있어요. 우리가 의사였다면 "그건 절대 용납할 수 없다"고 했을 거예요.
text_zh: 为什么产品管理到现在还是个相对不成熟的领域呢？我们都搞了15到20年了，但产品管理的现状就是抓不住真正重要的东西，真正有价值的东西。如果我们是医生的话，你肯定会说"这完全不能接受啊"。
text_es: ¿Por qué la gestión de productos sigue siendo una disciplina tan poco desarrollada? Ya llevamos como 15 o 20 años en esto, y hay algo en el estado actual del product management que no está llegando a lo realmente importante, a las cosas que realmente aportan valor. Si fuéramos médicos, dirías "Eso es totalmente inaceptable."
context: Lenny asks Shaun about his strong opinions on the state of product management and how most PMs are not that great. Shaun is reflecting on why product management as a discipline hasn't matured as much as it should have after 15-20 years. He explains that there's something fundamentally wrong with how product management is currently practiced, as it's not focusing on the truly valuable and important aspects of the role, leading to random outcomes and performance.
vocabulary_highlights: relatively undeveloped discipline, truly value-added things, totally unacceptable

speaker: Shaun Clowes
text: In everything always talk from the customer's perspective, from the market's perspective, from the competitor's perspective, the very small number of PMs do that. They get dragged into internal politics, they get dragged into scrum management or scrum execution or product delivery, and you just can't win that way.
text_ko: 모든 일에서는 항상 고객 관점에서, 시장 관점에서, 경쟁자 관점에서 얘기해야 해요. 그렇게 하는 프로덕트 매니저들(PMs)은 극히 소수예요. 대부분은 사내 정치(internal politics)에 휘말리거나 스크럼 관리(scrum management)나 스크럼 실행(scrum execution), 제품 딜리버리(product delivery)에 끌려 들어가요. 그렇게는 절대 이길 수 없어요.
text_zh: 做任何事情都要站在客户角度、市场角度、竞争对手角度去考虑，但真正能做到这点的PM(产品经理)少之又少。他们总是被卷入内部斗争，被拖进敏捷管理或者产品交付这些事务性工作里，这样下去肯定是没戏的。
text_es: En todo siempre tienes que hablar desde la perspectiva del cliente, desde la perspectiva del mercado, desde la perspectiva de la competencia - muy pocos PMs hacen eso. Se dejan arrastrar por las políticas internas, se meten en la gestión del scrum o la ejecución del scrum o la entrega del producto, y así simplemente no puedes ganar.
context: Lenny asks Shaun for the solution to help PMs level up and become great product managers. Shaun explains that the fundamental problem is most PMs spend too much time looking inside the building rather than outside. He emphasizes that PMs should always start from external perspectives - customer, market, and competitor viewpoints - but most get distracted by internal operational tasks and politics, which prevents them from being truly effective.
vocabulary_highlights: get dragged into, scrum execution, you just can't win that way

speaker: Shaun Clowes
text: Well, you've got this synthesis machine, which is this LLM thing that's going to help you do synthesis, but if it hasn't got all that data to do synthesis on top of, it's got nothing. And so that means that LLMs can only be as good as the data they are given and how recent that data is.
text_ko: 그러니까 합성 도구(synthesis machine)인 LLM(large language model)이 있어서 합성을 도와주긴 하는데요, 그게 작동하려면 바탕이 되는 데이터가 있어야 해요. 그런 데이터가 없다면 아무것도 할 수 없어요. 그래서 LLM은 주어진 데이터의 품질과 그 데이터의 최신성만큼만 성능을 낼 수 있어요.
text_zh: 你看，你有这个合成机器，就是这个大语言模型(LLM)，它能帮你做综合分析，但如果它没有足够的数据做基础，那就什么都干不了。所以说，LLM的效果完全取决于你给它什么样的数据，还有这些数据有多新。
text_es: Bueno, tienes esta máquina de síntesis, que es esto del LLM que te va a ayudar a hacer síntesis, pero si no tiene todos esos datos sobre los cuales hacer la síntesis, no tiene nada. Entonces eso significa que los LLMs solo pueden ser tan buenos como los datos que les das y qué tan actualizados estén esos datos.
context: Lenny asks about Shaun's hot take that AI will most impact product management through data management rather than models. Shaun explains that LLMs are essentially synthesis machines - they're very good at analyzing and synthesizing information, but they're completely dependent on the quality and recency of data fed to them. Without good data input, even the smartest LLM produces nothing valuable, making data management the critical bottleneck for AI success.
vocabulary_highlights: synthesis machine, LLM thing, it's got nothing

speaker: Shaun Clowes
text: People really underestimate where the value is created in these applications and they just kind of get it completely wrong.
text_ko: 사람들이 이런 애플리케이션(applications)에서 가치가 실제로 어디서 창출되는지를 정말 과소평가하고, 그래서 그냥 완전히 잘못 판단해요.
text_zh: 大家真的是小看了这些应用程序的价值到底在哪儿创造出来的，基本上是完全搞错了方向。
text_es: La gente de verdad no entiende dónde se genera el valor en estas aplicaciones y simplemente se equivocan por completo.
context: Lenny asks about the future of B2B SaaS businesses if AI makes it easy to clone applications like Salesforce or Atlassian - whether these companies will be in trouble. Shaun responds that people fundamentally misunderstand where the real value lies in these enterprise applications. He's setting up to explain that the value isn't just in the user interface or basic functionality that can be easily replicated, but in something much deeper and harder to clone.
vocabulary_highlights: really underestimate, get it completely wrong

speaker: Shaun Clowes
text: They get dragged into internal politics, they get dragged into scrum management or scrum execution or product delivery, like elements of the delivery thing and you just can't win that way. You just can't win that way. You can never get an A because you're fundamentally not solving the job.
text_ko: 사람들이 내부 정치(internal politics)에 말려들고, 스크럼 관리(scrum management)나 스크럼 실행(scrrum execution), 제품 전달(product delivery) 같은 전달 관련 업무에 끌려 들어가요. 그렇게는 이길 수 없어요. 근본적으로 맡은 일을 해결하지 못하면 A를 받을 수가 없어요.
text_zh: 他们被卷入内部政治斗争，被拖进敏捷管理(scrum management)或者敏捷执行(scrum execution)，还有产品交付这些执行层面的事情里，这样下去肯定是赢不了的。真的赢不了。你永远拿不到A，因为根本就没有解决核心问题。
text_es: Se meten en las políticas internas, se dejan arrastrar por la gestión de scrum o la ejecución de scrum o la entrega de productos, o sea, todas esas cosas operativas, y así simplemente no puedes ganar. Así no puedes ganar. Nunca vas a sacar una A porque en el fondo no estás resolviendo el verdadero problema.
context: Lenny asks Shaun what makes PMs become great 10x product managers. Shaun explains that the biggest mistake most PMs make is spending time on internal operational tasks rather than focusing on external market insights. He emphasizes that PMs who get caught up in delivery mechanics and internal politics cannot achieve excellence because they're not addressing the core job of product management, which is finding reliable, differentiated value in the market.
vocabulary_highlights: get dragged into, you just can't win that way, never get an A, fundamentally not solving the job

speaker: Shaun Clowes
text: It's one thing to say you're spending a lot of time looking outside the building. It's a whole other thing to hear from the places you don't normally hear from. So avoid availability or confirmation bias. Most of the time people go talk to the people they always talk to and they learn nothing particularly new.
text_ko: 밖을 많이 보고 있다고 말하는 건 쉬운 일이에요. 그런데 평소 잘 듣지 않는 곳(혹은 사람들)으로부터 실제로 듣는 건 완전히 다른 얘기예요. 그래서 가용성 편향(availability bias)이나 확증 편향(confirmation bias)을 피하세요. 대부분 사람들은 늘 얘기하던 사람들한테만 가서 얘기하고, 특별히 새로 배울 게 별로 없어요.
text_zh: 嘴上说要多往外面看看是一回事，真正去听那些平时接触不到的声音又是另一回事。所以一定要避免可得性偏差(availability bias)和确认偏差(confirmation bias)。大多数时候人们就是找那些老面孔聊天，根本学不到什么新东西。
text_es: Una cosa es decir que estás dedicando mucho tiempo a mirar hacia afuera de la empresa. Pero algo completamente distinto es escuchar voces de lugares donde normalmente no escuchas nada. Así que evita el sesgo de disponibilidad o el sesgo de confirmación (confirmation bias). La mayoría de las veces la gente va y habla con las mismas personas de siempre y no aprende nada realmente nuevo.
context: Lenny asks how someone can recognize if they're actually not doing enough external research, even if they think they are. Shaun explains that many PMs claim to talk to customers and look at data frequently, but they fall into the trap of only seeking familiar sources and perspectives. He emphasizes the importance of actively seeking out unfamiliar viewpoints and challenging your own assumptions to avoid confirmation bias and truly learn something new.
vocabulary_highlights: It's a whole other thing, availability or confirmation bias, nothing particularly new

speaker: Shishir Mehrotra
speaker_expertise: Engineering Leadership, Growth Strategy, Team Building
text: The viral actions of a document platform are shared, create, share, create. It happens over and over and over again. The best way you learn about Office or Google Docs or so on is somebody shares one with you and you're like, "Oh, that's pretty cool. I bet I could create one." And that loop can happen very, very quickly and it really drives for us a lot of how we think about how we work mostly within companies and teams, but sometimes across them as well.
text_ko: 문서 플랫폼(document platform)에서 바이럴(viral)하게 퍼지는 행동 패턴은 '공유 → 만들기 → 공유 → 만들기'예요. 이게 계속해서 반복돼요. 오피스(Office)나 구글 문서(Google Docs)를 가장 잘 배우는 방법은 누군가가 하나를 공유해줘서 "아, 이거 괜찮네. 나도 만들어볼 수 있겠다"라고 느끼는 거예요. 그 루프(loop)는 아주 빠르게 일어나고, 우리한테는 주로 회사나 팀 내에서 일하는 방식을 생각하게 하는 큰 동력이 돼요. 가끔은 팀을 넘어서서도 일어나고요.
text_zh: 文档平台的病毒式传播动作就是分享、创建、分享、创建，这个循环不断重复。你了解Office或者Google Docs这些工具的最好方式，就是别人先分享给你一个文档，然后你就想"哎，这个挺不错的，我也能做一个"。这个循环可以非常非常快地发生，这很大程度上影响了我们对团队内部协作的思考方式，有时候也会影响跨团队的合作。
text_es: Las acciones virales de una plataforma de documentos son: compartir, crear, compartir, crear. Pasa una y otra vez sin parar. La mejor manera de conocer Office o Google Docs o cualquier otra es que alguien te comparta un documento y tú dices "Oye, qué padre está esto. Seguro yo también puedo crear uno". Y ese bucle puede pasar súper rápido y realmente nos ayuda muchísimo a entender cómo trabajamos, sobre todo dentro de las empresas y equipos, pero a veces también entre diferentes organizaciones.
context: Lenny asks Shishir to explain what Black Loops and Blue Loops are - a framework for understanding how Coda's product spreads. Shishir is describing the Black Loop, which he compares to Microsoft's document sharing model. The Black Loop works when someone creates a document, shares it with a group, and some subset of those people create their own documents, repeating the cycle. This viral sharing mechanism is fundamental to how document platforms naturally grow and spread within organizations.
vocabulary_highlights: viral actions, loop can happen very, very quickly

speaker: Shishir Mehrotra
speaker_expertise: Engineering Leadership, Growth Strategy, Team Building
text: If you take Black Loop and Blue Loop, the Black Loop is every product in our category has that. We didn't invent it. You build a document, you put a share button on it, every product has that. Sometimes it's just recognizing what's there. It's not that interesting. The Blue Loop on the other hand, is not something that every product in our category has.
text_ko: 블랙 루프(Black Loop)랑 블루 루프(Blue Loop)를 보면, 블랙 루프는 우리 카테고리의 모든 제품이 가지고 있어요. 우리가 발명한 건 아니에요. 문서를 만들고 공유 버튼을 달면 되는 기능이라서, 사실 모든 제품에 다 있어요. 가끔은 그냥 이미 있는 걸 인지하는 수준이라서 별로 흥미롭지 않아요. 반면 블루 루프(Blue Loop)는 우리 카테고리의 모든 제품이 갖고 있는 건 아니에요.
text_zh: 你看，如果把黑色循环(Black Loop)和蓝色循环(Blue Loop)拿来比较的话，黑色循环其实我们这个行业里每个产品都有，不是我们发明的。就是你做个文档，加个分享按钮，每个产品都这么干，有时候就是把现有的东西认识一下而已，没什么特别的。但是蓝色循环就不一样了，不是我们这个品类里每个产品都有的。
text_es: Si tomas el Bucle Negro (Black Loop) y el Bucle Azul (Blue Loop), el Bucle Negro es algo que todos los productos de nuestra categoría tienen. No lo inventamos nosotros. Creas un documento, le pones un botón para compartir, todos los productos tienen eso. A veces se trata simplemente de reconocer lo que ya está ahí. No es tan interesante. El Bucle Azul, por otro lado, no es algo que todos los productos de nuestra categoría tengan.
context: Lenny asks Shishir how founders can identify their own loops and flywheels for growth. Shishir explains that while the Black Loop (document sharing) exists in every document product and isn't unique to Coda, the Blue Loop represents their unique innovation. The Blue Loop allows users to publish documents publicly to the world, creating a publishing platform that acts like a hybrid between Medium and an app store, which differentiates Coda from competitors like Google Docs.
vocabulary_highlights: recognizing what's there, not that interesting

speaker: Shishir Mehrotra
speaker_expertise: Engineering Leadership, Growth Strategy, Team Building
text: And one reason it's very important is because for products like ours that are very horizontal, you get different types of users. There's some users that I call the building block thinkers, they like to build up from scratch and the blank surface of Coda is really amazing for them, but for most people that's intimidating. I don't really know what to do. Most people in the world are problem solvers.
text_ko: 중요한 이유 중 하나는 우리처럼 범용적인 제품(horizontal)은 다양한 유형의 사용자를 갖는다는 거예요. 제가 '구성요소형 사고를 하는 사용자들(building block thinkers)'이라고 부르는 분들이 있는데, 이분들은 처음부터 하나씩 쌓아 올리는 걸 좋아해서 Coda의 빈 화면(blank surface)이 정말 잘 맞아요. 그런데 대부분의 사람들에겐 그게 오히려 부담스러워요 — 어디서부터 시작해야 할지 모르겠다고 느끼거든요. 세상 사람들 대부분은 문제 해결자(problem solvers)이에요.
text_zh: 这个特别重要的一个原因是，像我们这种横向产品(horizontal product)，会有各种不同类型的用户。有些用户我叫他们"搭积木型思维者"，他们喜欢从零开始搭建，Coda的空白界面对他们来说简直太棒了。但对大多数人来说，这挺吓人的，不知道该从哪儿下手。其实世界上大部分人都是解决问题型的。
text_es: Y una razón por la que esto es súper importante es porque para productos como el nuestro que son muy horizontales, te llegan diferentes tipos de usuarios. Hay algunos usuarios que yo llamo los pensadores de bloques de construcción (building block thinkers), a ellos les encanta construir desde cero y la superficie en blanco de Coda les resulta increíble, pero para la mayoría de la gente eso les da cosa. No saben realmente qué hacer. La mayoría de las personas en el mundo son solucionadores de problemas.
context: Shishir continues explaining how the Blue Loop helps Coda reach different user types. He's describing why the Blue Loop publishing mechanism is crucial for horizontal products like Coda. While some users enjoy starting from a blank document (building block thinkers), most people are intimidated by that approach and prefer to start with a specific problem they need to solve. The Blue Loop allows problem-solvers to discover Coda through templates and solutions rather than being confronted with an empty document.
vocabulary_highlights: building block thinkers, build up from scratch, blank surface

speaker: Shishir Mehrotra
speaker_expertise: Engineering Leadership, Growth Strategy, Team Building
text: I highly encourage drawing a diagram like this for your business. I'll flash it up on screen for a second and I'll describe it, but this is what the diagram looks like, black loop, blue loop, and it's basically the two different ways that our product spreads.
text_ko: 여러분 비즈니스에 이런 다이어그램(diagram)을 그려보시길 강력히 권해요. 잠깐 화면에 띄워 보여드리고 설명할게요. 이 다이어그램은 블랙 루프(black loop)와 블루 루프(blue loop)로 되어 있고, 기본적으로 우리 제품이 퍼지는 두 가지 방식이에요.
text_zh: 我强烈建议你们也给自己的业务画这样一个图。我在屏幕上放一下，简单描述一下，就是这个样子——黑色循环，蓝色循环，基本上就是我们产品传播的两种不同路径。
text_es: Te recomiendo muchísimo que hagas un diagrama como este para tu negocio. Lo voy a poner en pantalla un momento y te lo explico, pero así se ve el diagrama: bucle negro, bucle azul, y básicamente son las dos formas distintas en que se extiende nuestro producto.
context: Lenny asks Shishir to explain what Black Loops and Blue Loops are as a framework for understanding growth strategy. Shishir is introducing a visual diagram that maps out Coda's ecosystem and growth mechanisms. He emphasizes that most businesses should create similar diagrams to understand how their products actually grow and spread, rather than thinking about growth as a linear funnel. This diagram became central to how Coda thinks about their business model and growth strategy.
vocabulary_highlights: flash it up on screen

speaker: Shishir Mehrotra
speaker_expertise: Engineering Leadership, Growth Strategy, Team Building
text: Great companies has a very small list of golden rituals. And there are three rules of golden rituals. Number one, they're named. Number two, every employee knows them by their first Friday and, number three, they're templated.
text_ko: 위대한 회사들은 아주 소수의 골든 리추얼(golden rituals)만 갖고 있어요. 골든 리추얼에는 세 가지 규칙이 있어요. 첫째, 이름이 붙어 있어요. 둘째, 모든 직원이 입사 첫 금요일까지는 그걸 알고 있어요. 셋째, 형식이 정해져 있어요(templated).
text_zh: 优秀的公司都有一套核心仪式感，而且数量不多。这些黄金仪式(golden rituals)有三个特点：第一，都有专门的名字；第二，每个员工入职第一周就必须熟悉；第三，都有标准化的模板和流程。
text_es: Las empresas exitosas tienen una lista muy pequeña de rituales de oro (golden rituals). Y hay tres reglas para estos rituales de oro. Primera, tienen nombre propio. Segunda, todos los empleados los conocen desde su primer viernes en la empresa. Y tercera, están sistematizados con plantillas.
context: Lenny asks Shishir how he got interested in rituals enough to write a book about them. Shishir shares a quote from Bing Gordon, a founder of Electronic Arts, that became the foundation for his book "The Rituals of Great Teams." This quote defines what makes organizational rituals effective and memorable. Golden rituals are the key practices that define a company's culture and operational excellence, with examples including Amazon's six-pagers, Google's OKRs, and Salesforce's V2MOM framework.
vocabulary_highlights: golden rituals, by their first Friday, they're templated

speaker: Shishir Mehrotra
speaker_expertise: Engineering Leadership, Growth Strategy, Team Building
text: The eigenquestion, the simplest definition of eigenquestion, it's the question that when answered also answers the most subsequent questions. And it's a very simple idea that when you sit down and you say, hey, here's all these questions we ought to answer, how do we all usually rank them? Sometimes we rank them just by what order we came up with them. Sometimes we rank them by importance, which is the most impactful decision we're going to make. But this methodology says don't rank them that way.
text_ko: 아이겐 질문(eigenquestion)은 가장 단순한 정의로 말하면, 그 질문에 답하면 이후에 이어지는 질문들까지 가장 많이 해결되는 질문이에요. 아주 간단한 아이디어예요. 우리가 앉아서 “여기 답해야 할 질문들이 다 있네”라고 할 때 보통 어떻게 우선순위를 매기죠? 가끔은 떠오른 순서대로 정하고, 가끔은 중요도, 즉 가장 큰 영향을 줄 결정부터 정해요. 그런데 이 방법론은 그렇게 순위를 매기지 말라고 해요.
text_zh: 本征问题(eigenquestion)，最简单的定义就是，当你解决了这个问题，其他一大堆问题也就迎刃而解了。这个概念其实很简单，就是当你坐下来说"好，我们有这么多问题需要解决"的时候，我们通常怎么排优先级呢？有时候我们就按想到的先后顺序来排，有时候按重要程度排，看哪个决策影响最大。但这套方法论告诉我们，别这么排。
text_es: La eigenpregunta, la definición más sencilla de eigenpregunta, es la pregunta que cuando la contestas, también te da respuesta a la mayor cantidad de preguntas que vienen después. Y es una idea muy simple: cuando te sientas y dices, oye, aquí tenemos todas estas preguntas que deberíamos responder, ¿cómo las priorizamos normalmente? A veces las ordenamos simplemente por el orden en que se nos ocurrieron. A veces las ordenamos por importancia, cuál va a ser la decisión con mayor impacto. Pero esta metodología dice que no las ordenes así.
context: Lenny asks Shishir to explain what eigenquestions are, referencing one of his most popular posts. Shishir defines the core concept after telling the story of YouTube's "Modern Family question" - a strategic dilemma about whether to link users to content on other sites. An eigenquestion is named after the mathematical concept of eigenvectors and represents the most discriminating question in a decision space. Rather than ranking questions by order or importance, this methodology prioritizes the question that, when answered, eliminates the need to answer many other related questions.
vocabulary_highlights: subsequent questions, most impactful decision, this methodology

speaker: Shreyas Doshi
text: And that force is a scope. Okay, so as we grow in our product career, our scope grows, and we kind of like that, which is all great, but at some point, if you haven't already gotten there, many of you have, but for those of you who haven't, you will get there, where your scope will be so large, that no matter what you do in terms of efficiency, whatever framework you use for prioritization, whatever framework or tool you use to manage your to-do list, whatever tools and techniques you use, whatever prioritization you do, your scope is so large that you are still going to be incredibly busy.
text_ko: 그 힘은 바로 스코프(scope)예요. 프로덕트 경력(product career)이 쌓일수록 담당 스코프가 넓어지고, 우리도 그걸 좋아해요. 그런데 어느 순간(이미 도달하신 분들도 많겠지만 아직 아닌 분들도 있을 거예요), 스코프가 너무 커져서 아무리 효율성(efficiency)을 높이고, 어떤 우선순위(prioritization) 프레임워크(framework)를 쓰고, 어떤 할 일 목록(to-do list) 관리 도구나 기법을 써도 결국 엄청 바쁠 수밖에 없어요.
text_zh: 而这个力量就是范围。好吧，随着我们在产品生涯中不断成长，我们的工作范围也在扩大，我们也挺喜欢这样的，这都挺好的，但是到了某个节点——如果你还没到那个程度的话，你们很多人已经经历过了，但对于那些还没经历过的人来说，你们迟早会遇到——你的工作范围会变得非常大，无论你在效率方面做什么努力，无论你用什么框架来排优先级，无论你用什么框架或工具来管理你的待办事项(to-do list)，无论你用什么工具和技巧，无论你怎么排优先级，你的工作范围就是这么大，你还是会忙得不可开交。
text_es: Y esa fuerza es el alcance. Bueno, entonces conforme vamos creciendo en nuestra carrera de producto, nuestro alcance crece, y como que nos gusta eso, lo cual está genial, pero en algún momento, si no han llegado ya ahí, muchos de ustedes ya llegaron, pero para los que no, van a llegar, donde su alcance va a ser tan grande, que no importa lo que hagan en términos de eficiencia, cualquier metodología que usen para priorizar, cualquier metodología o herramienta que usen para manejar su lista de pendientes, cualesquiera herramientas y técnicas que usen, cualquier priorización que hagan, su alcance es tan grande que de todas formas van a estar increíblemente ocupados.
context: Lenny asks Shreyas about his first question, which is 'Why am I so busy?' Shreyas explains that he spent most of his career feeling extremely stressed and busy despite working hard. He discusses how productivity tips and time management techniques can help initially, but eventually hit a wall. Shreyas identifies scope expansion as the core issue - as you advance in your career, your responsibilities grow to a point where no amount of efficiency improvements can keep up.
vocabulary_highlights: immovable force, framework you use for prioritization, no matter what you do in terms of efficiency
topics: Leadership & Management, Career Development, Work-Life Balance

speaker: Shreyas Doshi
text: And so what I realized, Lenny, is you don't have to go through these four to six weeks, and it was an accident. Basically, what happened is around that time, the product I was working on, Stripe Connect, it's like a major product for Stripe, major, major business for Stripe. And I had put together a product strategy, like a real product strategy for this product.
text_ko: 그래서 제가 깨달은 건, 레니, 꼭 4~6주를 거칠 필요는 없다는 거였어요. 그리고 그건 우연히 그렇게 된 일이었어요. 사실 그때 제가 맡고 있던 제품인 스트라이프 커넥트(Stripe Connect)는 스트라이프에게 정말 큰 제품이자 핵심 사업이었고, 저는 그 제품을 위해 진짜 제품 전략(product strategy)을 세웠어요.
text_zh: 所以我发现，Lenny，其实你不用非得花那四到六周的时间，这完全是个意外发现。基本上是这样的，当时我在做的那个产品 Stripe Connect，这可是 Stripe 的核心产品，对 Stripe 来说是超级重要的业务。然后我为这个产品制定了一个产品策略，就是那种真正的产品策略。
text_es: Y entonces lo que me di cuenta, Lenny, es que no tienes que pasar por esas cuatro a seis semanas, y fue de casualidad. Básicamente, lo que pasó es que por esa época, el producto en el que estaba trabajando, Stripe Connect, es como un producto súper importante para Stripe, un negocio súper, súper importante para Stripe. Y había armado una estrategia de producto, o sea, una estrategia de producto de verdad para este producto.
context: Lenny asks about Shreyas' experience with annual planning cycles that typically consume 4-6 weeks. Shreyas describes how most teams go through elaborate planning rituals, create detailed plans, but then abandon them within weeks due to customer escalations and changing priorities. He explains how having a genuine product strategy (not a superficial one) allowed him to complete his planning for a major Stripe product in just three days instead of the usual lengthy process.
vocabulary_highlights: it was an accident, major, major business, real product strategy
topics: Strategy & Planning, Product Management, Leadership & Management

speaker: Shreyas Doshi
text: The challenge here with this kind of approach, and again, this is what happens in practice, I'm not talking about whatever theory you read, this is what happens in practice. So when you follow this approach and you assume that, 'Oh, this is a two-way door, we can kill the feature,' in reality, it doesn't work out that way, because here's what happens in reality.
text_ko: 문제는 이런 방식인데, 다시 말하지만 이건 읽은 이론 얘기가 아니라 실제로 현장에서 일어나는 일이에요. 그래서 이 접근을 따르면서 ‘이건 되돌릴 수 있는 결정(two-way door)이니까 기능을 지워도 괜찮다’고 가정하면, 현실은 그렇게 안 돌아가요. 실제로는 이런 일이 벌어지거든요.
text_zh: 这种做法的问题在于，我再强调一遍，这是实际操作中会遇到的情况，我说的不是你在书上看到的那些理论，而是真正干活时碰到的事儿。所以当你采用这种方法，心想"没事，这是个可逆决策(two-way door)，大不了砍掉这个功能"，但现实中根本不是这么回事，因为实际情况是这样的。
text_es: El problema con este tipo de enfoque, y otra vez, esto es lo que pasa en la práctica, no estoy hablando de cualquier teoría que hayas leído, esto es lo que pasa en la práctica. Entonces cuando sigues este enfoque y asumes que, 'Ah, esta es una puerta de doble vía, podemos matar la funcionalidad,' en realidad, no funciona así, porque esto es lo que pasa en realidad.
context: Lenny and Shreyas are discussing why product managers stay so busy. Shreyas explains that one major reason is making poor product decisions, often justified by concepts like 'two-way doors' (reversible decisions). He argues that while these decisions seem reversible in theory, in practice they become one-way commitments. Teams make quick feature decisions without properly thinking through customer motivation, differentiation, or distribution strategy, assuming they can easily reverse course later.
vocabulary_highlights: this kind of approach, whatever theory you read, it doesn't work out that way
topics: Product Management, Decision Making, Strategy & Planning

speaker: Shreyas Doshi
text: We use data when it favors us, we use anecdotes when it favors us. So anyway, so we present that. Now we do have the sales counterpart in the room too, our sales counterpart, and they say, 'You know what, though? We are still not winning many deals because of this feature.' And so of course the CEO asks, 'So what's up? Why aren't we winning deals, even though we have the feature?'
text_ko: 우리는 유리할 때는 데이터(data)를 쓰고, 유리할 때는 일화(anecdotes)를 들곤 해요. 어쨌든 그렇게 제시해요. 그리고 여기 우리 영업 담당자(sales counterpart)도 있는데, 그쪽은 "사실 이 기능(feature) 때문에 아직도 많은 계약(deals)을 못 따고 있어요"라고 말해요. 그러면 당연히 CEO는 "무슨 일이에요? 기능이 있는데도 왜 계약을 못 따는 거예요?"라고 물어봐요.
text_zh: 我们有利的数据就拿数据说话，有利的案例就拿案例说事儿。反正就是这么汇报的。不过销售那边的同事也在场，他们就说："话虽如此，但是我们因为这个功能成交的单子还是不多。" CEO当然就问了："怎么回事？我们明明有这个功能，为什么还是拿不下单子？"
text_es: Usamos los datos cuando nos convienen, usamos las anécdotas cuando nos convienen. Bueno, el caso es que presentamos eso. Ahora, también tenemos al equipo de ventas ahí en la sala, y nos dicen: "Mira, la cosa es que todavía no estamos cerrando muchos negocios por esta funcionalidad." Y claro, el CEO pregunta: "¿Y qué pasa? ¿Por qué no estamos cerrando deals aunque tengamos la funcionalidad?"
context: Shreyas is explaining why product decisions that seem reversible ('two-way doors') actually trap teams in more work. He describes a common scenario where a feature launches with poor adoption, but during quarterly business reviews, product managers use favorable anecdotes to make it sound successful. However, when sales teams point out the feature isn't helping win deals, it forces the product team to commit to building additional features to make it 'table stakes' competitive.
vocabulary_highlights: when it favors us, sales counterpart, winning many deals
topics: Product Management, Decision Making, Communication Skills

speaker: Shreyas Doshi
text: But what we need to understand is it's game recognize game before the game is called, right? Like, game recognize game in the practice session. Because it takes no genius right now to say, 'Well, Patrick Mahomes is great quarterback,' or, 'Virat Kohli is a great cricketer,' or whatever else. It requires no genius to do that. It requires zero taste.
text_ko: 근데 우리가 이해해야 할 건, 경기가 시작되기 전에 이미 실력 있는 사람은 서로 알아본다는 거예요(game recognize game). 연습 세션에서부터 바로 드러나거든요. 지금 '패트릭 마홈스가 훌륭한 쿼터백이다'거나 '비랏 콜리가 훌륭한 크리켓 선수다'라고 말하는 데는 천재일 필요 없어요. 전혀 안목이나 특별한 감각이 필요한 얘기가 아니에요.
text_zh: 但是我们要明白的是，真正的高手在比赛开始之前就能相互认出对方，对吧？就是说，在练习的时候高手就能识别高手。因为现在谁都能说"帕特里克·马霍姆斯是个好四分卫"或者"维拉特·科利是个好板球手"什么的，这根本不需要什么眼光。完全不需要什么品味。
text_es: Pero lo que tenemos que entender es que hay que reconocer el talento antes de que se haga famoso, ¿no? O sea, hay que identificar a los buenos cuando todavía están en las prácticas. Porque ahora mismo cualquiera puede decir "Ay, Patrick Mahomes es un quarterbackazo" o "Virat Kohli es un crack del cricket" o lo que sea. Para eso no hace falta ser un genio. Eso no requiere ningún ojo clínico.
context: Lenny asks about Shreyas' second question: 'Do I actually have good taste?' Shreyas explains that taste isn't just about product design, but about the ability to identify what is truly good before its results are obvious. He uses the sports phrase 'game recognize game' to illustrate that real taste means recognizing excellence early, not after someone becomes obviously successful. He argues that calling Jensen Huang a genius in 2024 requires no taste since NVIDIA's success is evident, but recognizing his potential in 2010 would have demonstrated real insight.
vocabulary_highlights: game recognize game, before the game is called, it requires zero taste
topics: Leadership & Management, Decision Making, Learning & Growth

speaker: Shreyas Doshi
text: So I see this in everything. Like, let's see, the other one is we also get very impressed with complicated charts and math we don't understand. And some of you product leaders who are at the top of the game, you actually use this as a strategy.
text_ko: 저는 이걸 모든 곳에서 봐요. 예를 들면, 또 하나는 우리가 이해하지 못하는 복잡한 차트나 수학에 너무 쉽게 감탄한다는 거예요. 그리고 업계 최고 수준의 프로덕트 리더(product leaders)들 중에는 이걸 전략으로 일부러 쓰는 분들도 있어요.
text_zh: 所以我发现这种情况到处都是。比如说，另外一个就是我们特别容易被那些复杂的图表和看不懂的数学搞得一愣一愣的。你们当中一些顶尖的产品负责人，其实就是把这个当策略在用。
text_es: Entonces esto lo veo en todo. O sea, mira, otra cosa es que también nos impresionamos mucho con gráficos complicados y matemáticas que no entendemos. Y algunos de ustedes que son líderes de producto que están en la cima, en realidad usan esto como estrategia.
context: Shreyas continues discussing the question 'Do I actually have good taste?' He's explaining how product leaders often get swayed by superficial factors rather than substance. He points out that people are attracted to catchy metaphors (like 'two-way doors' vs 'reversible decisions') and alliterations (like 'fail fast' vs 'fail quickly') rather than evaluating ideas on merit. He suggests that some senior product leaders deliberately use complicated presentations to appear more authoritative, exploiting these psychological biases.
vocabulary_highlights: get very impressed with, at the top of the game, use this as a strategy
topics: Leadership & Management, Decision Making, Communication Skills

speaker: Shreyas Doshi
text: So when I realized this, I said, when a team grew to a certain size, so when I was at Stripe and I realized this, when the team I was managing, it had a fan out of about 50 people, so this includes engineers and everything, I said, 'This is enough.' Because for me, any time a team goes to like 50s, and 100s, and beyond, it is a law of corporations that you're going to have to spend a lot of time at the optics level.
text_ko: 그래서 이걸 깨달았을 때 저는 이렇게 생각했어요. 팀이 어느 정도 규모로 커지면—스트라이프에 있을 때 제가 맡고 있던 팀의 팬아웃(fan-out)이 엔지니어 포함해서 대략 50명이었는데—'이 정도면 충분하다'고요. 제 경험상 팀이 50명대, 100명대, 그 이상으로 가면 회사의 불문율처럼 '옵틱스 수준(optics level)'에 많은 시간을 써야 해요.
text_zh: 所以当我意识到这一点的时候，我就想，当一个团队发展到一定规模的时候——那时候我在Stripe，我意识到这个问题——当我管理的团队，包括工程师什么的，总共有50个人左右的时候，我就说："够了。" 因为对我来说，任何时候团队规模到了50人、100人或者更多，按照公司的规律，你就必须花大量时间在表面功夫上。
text_es: Entonces cuando me di cuenta de esto, dije, cuando un equipo creció hasta cierto tamaño, o sea cuando estaba en Stripe y me di cuenta de esto, cuando el equipo que yo manejaba tenía como unas 50 personas bajo mi responsabilidad, incluyendo ingenieros y todo, dije: "Ya es suficiente." Porque para mí, cada vez que un equipo llega a los 50, y después a los 100 y más allá, es una ley de las corporaciones que vas a tener que pasar muchísimo tiempo ocupándote de las apariencias.
context: Lenny asks about Shreyas' third question: 'Why does my job feel so frustrating?' Shreyas explains that frustration comes from operating misaligned with your superpowers. He describes three levels of product work: impact, execution, and optics. While his happy place was the impact level, corporate growth forced him to spend more time on optics (managing up, presentations, politics). At Stripe, he deliberately capped his team size at 50 people to avoid spending most of his time on optics work, choosing alignment with his strengths over traditional career advancement.
vocabulary_highlights: fan out of about 50 people, law of corporations, optics level
topics: Leadership & Management, Career Development, Work-Life Balance

speaker: Shreyas Doshi
text: The genius of the pre-mortem ritual is the initial prompt. So it's not just about like, well, what could go wrong? The initial prompt is the genius, which is the prompt starts with, imagine this project that we are working on has failed six months from now, or this launch we are doing has miserably failed. Let's just all imagine that. Now, let's work backwards from there and ask ourselves what went wrong, what could have contributed to this utter failure.
text_ko: 사전 실패 시뮬레이션(pre-mortem) 의식의 천재성은 바로 초기 프롬프트(prompt)에 있어요. 단순히 “뭐가 잘못될까?” 하는 수준이 아니라, 핵심은 처음에 던지는 질문이에요. 그 질문은 이렇게 시작하죠. “우리가 지금 하고 있는 이 프로젝트가 6개월 뒤에 실패했다고 상상해 보세요,” 또는 “이번 론칭이 처참하게 실패했다고 가정해 봅시다.” 자, 그럼 그 상태에서 역으로 거슬러 올라가 무엇이 잘못됐는지, 어떤 요인들이 이런 완전한 실패에 기여했을지를 함께 찾아보는 거예요.
text_zh: 事前验尸(pre-mortem)这个方法最厉害的地方就在于一开始怎么问问题。不是简单地问"会出什么问题"，关键是一开始就要这样想：假设我们现在做的这个项目，六个月后彻底搞砸了，或者我们要上线的东西完全失败了。大家先这样想象一下。然后我们倒推回来，想想到底哪里出了问题，什么原因导致了这次惨败。
text_es: La genialidad del ritual de pre-mortem está en cómo empiezas. O sea, no se trata solo de preguntarse "¿qué podría salir mal?" La clave está en el planteamiento inicial, que empieza así: imagínense que este proyecto en el que estamos trabajando fracasó completamente dentro de seis meses, o que este lanzamiento que vamos a hacer fue un desastre total. Vamos todos a imaginarnos eso. Ahora, trabajemos hacia atrás desde ahí y preguntémonos qué salió mal, qué pudo haber contribuido a este fracaso absoluto.
context: Lenny asks Shreyas to explain the concept of pre-mortems, which is something he's shared on Twitter that has resonated with many people. Shreyas explains that pre-mortems are the opposite of post-mortems - instead of analyzing what went wrong after a project fails, you proactively imagine failure at the beginning of a project. The key insight is using a specific prompt that asks the team to work backwards from an imagined failure scenario to identify potential risks before they occur.
vocabulary_highlights: work backwards from, utter failure, miserably failed
topics: Product Management, Strategy & Planning, Decision Making

speaker: Shreyas Doshi
text: I noticed consistently over the years that as I started thinking about what differentiates the PMs who've had just a large impact and even more important than just impact to the company or to the team, PMs who've surprised me in a positive way, PMs who've really exceeded expectations, exceeded perhaps their own capabilities on paper. You see somebody's credentials on paper and then you see their work and their impact. And there's a big difference between what you might assume on paper and the impact they're achieving.
text_ko: 제가 수년 동안 꾸준히 느낀 건, 큰 임팩트를 낸 프로덕트 매니저(PM)들과, 더 중요한 건 팀이나 회사에 실질적 영향을 주면서도 저를 긍정적으로 놀라게 한—기대치를 훨씬 넘긴—프로덕트 매니저들이 무엇으로 차별화되는지 생각해 보면 공통된 패턴이 있다는 점이에요. 이력서나 스펙만 보면 어떤 사람일지 짐작하게 되는데, 실제로 그 사람이 만들어내는 성과와 영향력은 종종 종이에 적힌 것과 크게 달라요.
text_zh: 这些年我一直观察发现，那些真正有巨大影响力的PM(产品经理)，不只是对公司或团队有贡献，更重要的是那些让我刮目相看的PM，那些真正超出预期的PM，甚至超越了他们纸面实力的PM。你看他们简历上的背景资历，再看他们实际的工作表现和影响力，纸面印象和实际成果之间往往差别很大。
text_es: Me he dado cuenta a lo largo de los años que cuando me pongo a pensar en qué diferencia a los PMs que han tenido un impacto enorme, y más importante aún que el impacto para la empresa o el equipo, son los PMs que me han sorprendido para bien, PMs que realmente han superado las expectativas, que han ido más allá de lo que parecían capaces sobre el papel. Ves el currículum de alguien y luego ves su trabajo y su impacto real. Y hay una diferencia abismal entre lo que podrías asumir viendo su papel y el impacto que realmente están logrando.
context: Lenny brings up the concept of high agency as an important trait for product managers. Shreyas explains his observations about what separates high-performing PMs from those who underperform relative to their potential. He's noticed that some PMs consistently exceed expectations despite not having the most impressive backgrounds, while others with great credentials fail to achieve their potential in practice.
vocabulary_highlights: capabilities on paper, exceeded expectations, assume on paper
topics: Product Management, Leadership & Management, Career Development

speaker: Shreyas Doshi
text: When you combine high energy sound judgment, low ego and small teams, you just get magic. And so, Stripe wasn't by any means flawless, but I saw that combination of high energy sound judgment, low ego and small teams more at Stripe than any other place I've been at. And so, that was very impactful and my growth and thinking as a leader.
text_ko: 높은 에너지와 건전한 판단력(high energy, sound judgment), 자만심이 낮은 태도(low ego), 소규모 팀(small teams)을 결합하면 진짜 마법 같은 일이 일어나요. Stripe가 결함이 전혀 없던 건 아니지만, 제가 가본 어느 곳보다도 그 조합을 Stripe에서 더 자주 봤어요. 그래서 그 경험이 제 리더로서의 성장과 생각에 큰 영향을 미쳤어요.
text_zh: 当你把高能量、靠谱的判断力、低姿态还有小团队这几个东西组合在一起的时候，就会产生神奇的化学反应。Stripe当然不是完美无缺的，但是我在那里看到的这种高能量、靠谱判断力、低姿态加上小团队的组合，比我去过的任何地方都要明显。这对我作为领导者的成长和思维方式影响特别大。
text_es: Cuando combinas mucha energía con buen criterio, poco ego y equipos pequeños, simplemente surge la magia. Y mira, Stripe no era para nada perfecto, pero vi esa combinación de mucha energía, buen criterio, poco ego y equipos pequeños más en Stripe que en cualquier otro lugar donde haya estado. Y eso me impactó muchísimo en mi crecimiento y forma de pensar como líder.
context: Lenny asks Shreyas what he took away from each of the major tech companies he worked at - Yahoo, Google, Twitter, and Stripe. Shreyas is explaining the key lesson he learned at Stripe about what creates exceptional team performance. He observed that when you combine four specific elements together, it creates an almost magical level of productivity and results.
vocabulary_highlights: sound judgment, low ego, by any means flawless

speaker: Shreyas Doshi
