text: Most execution problems that I encounter in a high performing environment where everybody has the right intentions are actually not execution problems, they are either strategy problems or interpersonal problems or cultural problems. And so, just to illustrate it, I'll make the observation that many leaders are extremely busy in such environments, whether it's a fast growth startup or a fast growth larger company, they're extremely busy, they're usually overwhelmed.
text_ko: 제가 모두 선한 의도를 가진 성과 높은 환경(high-performing environment)에서 접하는 실행 문제(execution problems)의 대부분은 사실 실행 자체의 문제라기보다 전략 문제(strategy problems)이거나 대인관계 문제(interpersonal problems), 혹은 문화적 문제(cultural problems)인 경우가 많아요. 예를 들어, 그런 환경에서는 빠르게 성장하는 스타트업(fast-growth startup)이든 빠르게 성장하는 더 큰 회사(fast-growth larger company)이든 많은 리더들이 정말 바쁘고, 보통은 감당하기 벅찰 정도로 과부하 상태예요.
text_zh: 在高绩效环境中，我遇到的大部分执行问题，其实大家的出发点都是好的，但真正的问题往往不是执行层面的，而是战略问题、人际关系问题，或者企业文化问题。举个例子来说明，很多领导者在这种环境下都特别忙，不管是快速增长的创业公司还是快速发展的大公司，他们都忙得不可开交，通常都是应接不暇的状态。
text_es: La mayoría de problemas de ejecución que me encuentro en entornos de alto rendimiento donde todos tienen buenas intenciones, en realidad no son problemas de ejecución - son problemas de estrategia, de relaciones interpersonales o de cultura organizacional. Para que se entienda mejor, déjame hacer esta observación: muchos líderes están súper ocupados en estos entornos, ya sea en una startup de crecimiento acelerado o en una empresa más grande que está creciendo rápido, están súper ocupados, normalmente están desbordados.
context: Lenny introduces Shreyas's fourth big idea about a provocative tweet claiming that most execution problems are actually strategy or culture problems. Shreyas explains this insight he discovered later in his career - that in high-performing organizations where people have good intentions, what appears to be poor execution is usually a symptom of deeper issues with strategy clarity or organizational culture, not actual execution capabilities.
vocabulary_highlights: right intentions, high performing environment, fast growth startup
topics: Strategy & Planning, Leadership & Management, Product Management

speaker: Shreyas Doshi
text: When you are in a high leverage role, you should stop doing work that simply provides a positive return on investment, ROI. And you should start focusing on work that minimizes opportunity cost and what drives that is the observation that in a high leverage role, so product management is good example of a high leverage role, founders by definition are in a high leverage role, engineering leaders, design leaders, designers, these are all fairly high leverage roles.
text_ko: 높은 레버리지 역할(high leverage role)에 있을 때는 단지 투자수익률(ROI)이 플러스인 일만 하지 마세요. 기회비용(opportunity cost)을 최소화하는 일에 집중해야 해요. 그 이유는 높은 레버리지 역할의 특성 때문인데—예를 들어 제품 관리(product management)가 좋은 사례고, 창업자들은 본질적으로 그런 역할을 맡고 있으며 엔지니어링 리더, 디자인 리더, 디자이너들도 모두 비교적 높은 레버리지 역할이에요.
text_zh: 当你处在高杠杆岗位上的时候，就别再做那些只是有正向投资回报率(ROI)的工作了。你应该把重点放在能够最小化机会成本的工作上。之所以这样说，是因为在高杠杆岗位中——比如产品经理就是个很典型的高杠杆岗位，创始人天然就在高杠杆岗位上，还有工程技术负责人、设计负责人、设计师，这些都算是杠杆效应比较强的岗位。
text_es: Cuando estás en un puesto de alto impacto, tienes que dejar de hacer trabajos que simplemente te dan un ROI positivo. Y tienes que enfocarte en el trabajo que minimiza el costo de oportunidad (opportunity cost), y lo que impulsa esto es darse cuenta de que en un rol de alto impacto - por ejemplo, la gestión de producto es un buen ejemplo de un rol de alto impacto, los fundadores por definición están en roles de alto impacto, líderes de ingeniería, líderes de diseño, diseñadores - todos estos son roles de bastante alto impacto.
context: Lenny introduces the fifth big idea about prioritization - instead of focusing on highest ROI work, Shreyas argues you should think about minimizing opportunity cost. Shreyas explains this counterintuitive approach to prioritization that he learned by observing Patrick Collison at Stripe. The insight is that people in high-leverage roles like product management have hundreds of positive ROI options, but focusing on ROI can lead to choosing quick wins over truly impactful work.
vocabulary_highlights: high leverage role, positive return on investment, by definition, minimizes opportunity cost
topics: Product Management, Strategy & Planning, Decision Making

speaker: Shreyas Doshi
text: The main thing Google taught me was the power of thinking really big. And I know it sounds like a platitude, but really big. And I only actually realized that when I left Google and I started working with the other teams and these were all capable teams and I was struck by how many teams just limited the potential of what they could achieve. And I think Google helped people think big by default.
text_ko: 구글이 제게 가장 크게 가르쳐준 건 정말 크게 생각하는 힘이에요. 상투적으로 들릴 수 있다는 건 알지만, 진짜로 ‘엄청나게’ 크게 생각하는 거예요. 그걸 진짜로 깨달은 건 구글을 떠나 다른 팀들과 일해보기 시작했을 때였어요. 그 팀들 모두 역량 있는 팀들이었는데도 스스로 성취 가능성을 제한하는 팀들이 의외로 많더라고요. 구글은 사람들로 하여금 기본적으로 크게 생각하게 만드는 환경이었다고 생각해요.
text_zh: 谷歌教给我最重要的一点就是要敢想敢做，格局要大。我知道这听起来像句空话，但真的要想得很大很大。我其实是离开谷歌之后才真正意识到这一点的，开始和其他团队合作时，这些团队都很有能力，但让我印象深刻的是，太多团队都在自我设限，把自己能达到的高度给框死了。我觉得谷歌的文化就是让大家习惯性地往大了想。
text_es: Lo principal que me enseñó Google fue el poder de pensar realmente en grande. Y sé que suena a lugar común, pero de verdad en grande. Y solo me di cuenta de esto cuando dejé Google y empecé a trabajar con otros equipos, y todos eran equipos capaces, pero me llamó la atención cómo tantos equipos simplemente se limitaban el potencial de lo que podían lograr. Y creo que Google ayudaba a la gente a pensar en grande por defecto.
context: Lenny asks Shreyas what key lesson he took away from each major tech company he worked at. Shreyas is explaining what he learned during his six years at Google. He emphasizes that while 'think big' sounds like a cliché, Google actually instilled this as a default mindset, which he only fully appreciated after leaving and seeing how other capable teams artificially constrained their ambitions.
vocabulary_highlights: sounds like a platitude, struck by, limited the potential, by default
topics: Strategy & Planning, Product Management, Leadership & Management

speaker: Shweta Shrivastava
speaker_expertise: Product Management, AI/ML Products, Growth Strategy
text: We're using a lot of human driving data to train our deep models. So it's important to make sure that the behavior of the car doesn't seem robotic, it can feel quite unnatural. And from the get-go, we focused on building a fully autonomous system. So it's important to have that familiarity, that trust, building with the riders where they're not daunted by technology, they don't feel like they're sitting in our walk. It has to feel very human-like, but in a good way.
text_ko: 우리는 사람이 운전한 데이터(human driving data)를 많이 써서 딥러닝 모델(deep models)을 학습시키고 있어요. 그래서 차량의 행동이 로봇처럼 느껴지면 안 돼요 — 그게 굉장히 어색하게 느껴질 수 있거든요. 처음부터 완전 자율주행 시스템(fully autonomous system) 구축에 집중해 왔기 때문에, 탑승자들과 친숙함과 신뢰를 쌓는 게 중요해요. 탑승자들이 기술에 위축되지 않고, ‘시험용 차량을 타고 있다’는 느낌을 받지 않게 해야 해요. 결국엔 좋은 의미로 아주 사람답게 느껴져야 해요.
text_zh: 我们用了大量的人类驾驶数据来训练我们的深度模型(deep models)。所以很重要的一点是，要确保车的行为不能显得太机械化，不然会让人觉得很不自然。从一开始我们就专注于打造完全自动驾驶系统(fully autonomous system)。所以很关键的是要让乘客有那种熟悉感，建立起信任，让他们不会被技术吓到，不会觉得自己坐在我们的实验品里。必须要有很人性化的感觉，但是是好的那种人性化。
text_es: Estamos usando muchísimos datos de conductores reales para entrenar nuestros modelos profundos (deep models). Entonces es súper importante asegurarnos de que el comportamiento del coche no se sienta robótico, porque puede resultar muy antinatural. Y desde el primer día nos enfocamos en construir un sistema completamente autónomo. Por eso es clave generar esa familiaridad, esa confianza con los pasajeros para que no se intimiden con la tecnología, para que no sientan que están montados en nuestro experimento. Tiene que sentirse muy humano, pero en el buen sentido.
context: Lenny asks about how Waymo creates body language and communication systems for their self-driving cars to interact with other drivers and pedestrians. Shweta explains that Waymo uses human driving data to train their AI models, but filters out bad driving behaviors. She emphasizes that the goal is to make the autonomous vehicle feel natural and trustworthy to riders, not robotic or intimidating, while still being safer than human driving.
vocabulary_highlights: from the get-go, daunted by technology, sitting in our walk

speaker: Shweta Shrivastava
speaker_expertise: Product Management, AI/ML Products, Growth Strategy
text: I would say that the PMC has to be able to go technically indeed, compared to what they would do in other software products. They have to be able to get into the details as much as needed. They have to be okay with uncertainty and ambiguity. Again, I think, that is part and parcel of any product management role, but it's even more so here.
text_ko: 제 생각에는 PMC는 다른 소프트웨어 제품들에서 하던 것과 비교해 기술적으로 더 깊이 들어갈 수 있어야 해요. 필요한 만큼 세부 사항까지 파고들 줄 알아야 하고, 불확실성과 모호함을 견딜 수 있어야 해요. 다시 말하지만, 그건 모든 제품 관리 역할(product management role)의 일부이긴 한데, 여기서는 훨씬 더 그렇다고 생각해요.
text_zh: 我觉得PMC必须要有很强的技术能力，比起做其他软件产品的时候要求更高。他们得能够深入到各种细节中去，需要多深就得多深。还有就是要能接受不确定性和模糊性。虽然说这些本来就是产品管理工作的一部分，但在这里要求会更高。
text_es: Yo diría que el PMC tiene que poder meterse de lleno en lo técnico, en comparación con lo que haría en otros productos de software. Tiene que poder profundizar en los detalles tanto como sea necesario. Tiene que estar cómodo con la incertidumbre y la ambigüedad. Otra vez, creo que eso es parte integral de cualquier rol de gestión de producto, pero aquí es aún más importante.
context: Lenny asks about the biggest differences between working at Waymo versus traditional software companies like Amazon or Cisco. Shweta explains that product managers at Waymo need different skills due to the technical complexity of autonomous driving systems. She describes how PMs must dive deeper into technical details and handle more uncertainty than they would in typical software product roles.
vocabulary_highlights: go technically indeed, part and parcel

speaker: Shweta Shrivastava
speaker_expertise: Product Management, AI/ML Products, Growth Strategy
text: The concept of MVP, which is so widely popular in the SaaS product management world or product management world, in general, has a whole new meaning here at Waymo when you work in a product like this because safety is on top of mind for all of us and can't really cut corners on safety. The MVP bar itself for safety is extremely high for us.
text_ko: 일반적으로 SaaS 제품 관리 분야(SaaS product management)나 제품 관리 전반(product management)에서 널리 통용되는 '최소 기능 제품(MVP)' 개념이, 이런 제품을 다루는 Waymo에서는 전혀 다른 의미예요. 우리 모두 안전을 최우선으로 생각하기 때문에 안전에 대해서는 절대로 대충할 수 없고, 안전 관점에서의 MVP 기준 자체가 우리에겐 굉장히 높아요.
text_zh: MVP这个概念在SaaS产品管理或者整个产品管理领域都特别火，但在我们Waymo这里，做这种产品的时候，这个概念就完全不一样了。因为安全是我们所有人最关心的事儿，在安全方面咱们真的不能偷工减料。对我们来说，MVP的安全门槛本身就定得特别高。
text_es: El concepto de MVP (minimum viable product), que es tan popular en el mundo de la gestión de productos SaaS o en general en product management, tiene un significado completamente distinto aquí en Waymo cuando trabajas en un producto como este, porque la seguridad es lo primero para todos nosotros y realmente no puedes escatimar en temas de seguridad. Para nosotros, el estándar mínimo del MVP en cuanto a seguridad está altísimo.
context: Lenny continues asking about differences between Waymo and traditional software companies. Shweta explains how the concept of Minimum Viable Product (MVP) - a core principle in software development where you release a basic version and iterate - works differently at Waymo. Because autonomous vehicles must prioritize safety above all else, their definition of 'minimum viable' still requires an extremely high safety standard, unlike typical software products where you can launch with basic features and improve over time.
vocabulary_highlights: cut corners on safety

speaker: Shweta Shrivastava
speaker_expertise: Product Management, AI/ML Products, Growth Strategy
text: At Amazon, I was the first PM and then I drove the team around it for a no-code application development platform called Honey Code. So that was a brand new service. Amazon had never delved in that space before. It was more infrastructure focused and this was first of its kind service that the team worked on. And this has played out many times in my career, and so I am a big believer in disrupting yourself before somebody else does it.
text_ko: 아마존에서 저는 첫 번째 PM이었고, 그 팀과 함께 코드 없이 애플리케이션을 개발할 수 있는 플랫폼인 Honey Code를 만들었어요. 그건 완전히 새로운 서비스였죠. 아마존은 그 분야에 한 번도 들어간 적이 없었고, 그동안은 인프라 중심이었거든요. 그래서 팀이 처음으로 이런 서비스를 개발한 거예요. 제 경력에서도 이런 경험이 여러 번 있었고, 그래서 저는 누군가가 저를 방해하기 전에 스스로 변화를 주는 게 중요하다고 믿어요.
text_zh: 在亚马逊的时候，我是第一个产品经理，后来带着团队做了一个叫Honey Code的无代码应用开发平台(no-code application development platform)。这是个全新的服务，亚马逊以前从来没涉足过这个领域。之前都是专注基础设施这块，这是团队做的第一个这种类型的服务。我职业生涯中这种情况遇到过很多次，所以我特别相信一个道理：与其等别人来颠覆你，不如自己先颠覆自己。
text_es: En Amazon, fui el primer PM y luego dirigí el equipo para una plataforma de desarrollo de aplicaciones sin código que se llamaba Honey Code. Era un servicio completamente nuevo. Amazon nunca se había metido en ese espacio antes. Se enfocaban más en infraestructura y este fue el primer servicio de este tipo en el que trabajó el equipo. Y esto me ha pasado muchas veces en mi carrera, así que creo firmemente en disrumpirte a ti mismo antes de que alguien más lo haga.
context: Lenny asks for a specific example of disrupting yourself before competitors do, which Shweta had mentioned as an important lesson for large companies. Shweta shares how she led Amazon's first no-code application development platform called Honey Code, which was completely new territory for Amazon since they had previously focused on infrastructure services. This exemplifies her philosophy that established companies must innovate in new areas before startups disrupt them.
vocabulary_highlights: drove the team around it, delved in that space, first of its kind, played out many times
topics: Product Management, Strategy & Planning, Starting a Company

speaker: Shweta Shrivastava
speaker_expertise: Product Management, AI/ML Products, Growth Strategy
text: I think a lot of that for me came by just being in different kind of situations and different kind of environments. And I think a lot of that for me came by just being in different kind of situations and different kind of environments.
text_ko: 저한테는 그런 부분들이 다양한 상황과 환경에 직접 있어 보면서 많이 생긴 것 같아요. 다시 말하면, 여러 상황과 환경을 직접 겪으면서 그런 것들이 더 많이 생겼던 것 같아요.
text_zh: 我觉得这主要是因为我接触了各种不同的情况和环境，在不同的场合都待过。我觉得这主要是因为我接触了各种不同的情况和环境，在不同的场合都待过。
text_es: Creo que gran parte de eso lo aprendí simplemente por estar en todo tipo de situaciones y ambientes diferentes. Y creo que gran parte de eso lo aprendí simplemente por estar en todo tipo de situaciones y ambientes diferentes.
context: Lenny asks Shweta what helped her most develop listening and empathy skills, which she identified as underrated PM skills. Shweta explains that these crucial soft skills can only be developed through repeated practice across diverse work environments. She emphasizes that working with different types of teams, from startups to large companies, helped her understand various perspectives and constraints that different stakeholders face.

speaker: Shweta Shrivastava
speaker_expertise: Product Management, AI/ML Products, Growth Strategy
text: Are you proactively trying to challenge your own assumptions is extremely important, right? As a big enough product manager as well as a seasoned product leader, if you're not doing enough of that, then I think you might not be listening. If there's no conflict, if there's no contention, then something is missing.
text_ko: 스스로의 가정을 적극적으로 의심하려고 노력하는 게 정말 중요해요, 그렇죠? 제품 매니저(product manager)이든 경험 많은 제품 리더(product leader)이든, 그걸 충분히 하지 않는다면 말을 제대로 듣고 있지 않을 수 있어요. 충돌이나 이견이 전혀 없다면 뭔가 빠져 있는 거예요.
text_zh: 你有没有主动去质疑自己的假设？这点特别重要，对吧？作为一个资深的产品经理(product manager)或者产品负责人(product leader)，如果你在这方面做得不够，那我觉得你可能没有真正在倾听。如果没有冲突，没有争议，那说明肯定哪里出了问题。
text_es: ¿Estás tratando de manera proactiva de cuestionar tus propias suposiciones? Eso es súper importante, ¿no? Como product manager con experiencia y líder de producto consolidado, si no estás haciendo suficiente de eso, entonces creo que tal vez no estés escuchando bien. Si no hay conflicto, si no hay debate, entonces algo está faltando.
context: Lenny and Shweta are discussing how to develop better listening skills as a product manager. Shweta offers a specific technique for improving listening abilities: actively questioning your own assumptions. She argues that experienced product managers should expect disagreement and debate - if everyone always agrees with you, it's likely because you're not truly listening to different perspectives or you're missing important viewpoints.
vocabulary_highlights: proactively trying to challenge, seasoned product leader

speaker: Shweta Shrivastava
speaker_expertise: Product Management, AI/ML Products, Growth Strategy
text: I'm going to say something that might sound a little cheeky, but I think the way to get promoted is to not want it too badly. It is about you have to focus on the impact. It's about having an impact and then doing what is right for the business. So not sort of optimizing things for your promotion, which look, we are all ambitious human beings.
text_ko: 좀 건방지게 들릴 수도 있지만, 제 생각엔 승진(promotion)을 너무 간절히 원하지 않는 게 오히려 도움이 돼요. 중요한 건 임팩트(impact)에 집중하는 거예요. 임팩트를 만들고 비즈니스(business)에 맞는 옳은 일을 하는 거죠. 승진을 위해 모든 걸 최적화하려고 하지 말라는 얘기예요 — 물론 우리 모두 야망 있는 사람들인 건 사실이지만요.
text_zh: 我要说句可能听起来有点调皮的话，但我觉得想要升职的诀窍就是别太急着要。关键是你得专注于影响力，要产生实际影响，然后做对公司有利的事情。不要为了升职而去优化一切，当然了，我们都是有野心的人嘛。
text_es: Voy a decir algo que tal vez suene un poco atrevido, pero creo que la manera de conseguir un ascenso es no desearlo demasiado. Se trata de que tienes que enfocarte en el impacto. Se trata de generar impacto y luego hacer lo que es mejor para el negocio. O sea, no optimizar las cosas para tu ascenso, que bueno, todos somos seres humanos ambiciosos.
context: Lenny asks Shweta for advice on getting promoted, given her experience being promoted many times and now promoting others. Shweta offers counterintuitive advice: don't focus too heavily on wanting the promotion itself. Instead, she suggests focusing on creating meaningful business impact and doing what's right for the company. She acknowledges this might sound contradictory since ambition is natural, but argues that obsessing over promotion can actually hurt your chances.
vocabulary_highlights: sound a little cheeky, optimizing things for your promotion

speaker: Sri Batchu
text: Rather than going into the specifics, one thing I'll say about the growth system today is if you were to look at what percentage of our business comes from outbound sales, paid marketing, field, and then a bunch of other channels and then you compare it against industry benchmarks, I think the secret sauce of Ramp is not that we've found a channel that's unique and that we've over-invested or under-invested. I think what we've done differently is we've really focused on making all of those investments very much driven by technology and data.
text_ko: 세부로 들어가기보다는 성장 시스템에 대해 한 가지만 말씀드리면요: 우리 비즈니스에서 아웃바운드 세일즈(outbound sales), 유료 마케팅(paid marketing), 필드(field), 그 밖의 여러 채널(channel)에서 각각 차지하는 비중을 보고 업계 벤치마크(industry benchmarks)와 비교해 보면, Ramp의 비결(secret sauce)은 어떤 독특한 채널을 찾아서 거기에 과도하게 혹은 부족하게 투자했다는 게 아니에요. 저희가 다르게 해온 건 그런 모든 투자를 기술과 데이터(technology and data)로 주도되게 만드는 데 정말 집중했다는 점이에요.
text_zh: 我就不细说具体的了，关于我们现在的增长体系，我可以这么说：如果你看看我们从主动销售(outbound sales)、付费营销(paid marketing)、地推(field)还有其他各种渠道来的业务占比，然后跟行业基准(industry benchmarks)对比一下，我觉得Ramp的秘诀(secret sauce)不是说我们找到了什么独特的渠道，或者在某个渠道上投入过多或过少。我们做得不一样的地方是，我们特别专注于用技术和数据来驱动所有这些投入。
text_es: Más que entrar en detalles específicos, algo que te puedo decir sobre nuestro sistema de crecimiento es que si te fijas en qué porcentaje de nuestro negocio viene de ventas directas (outbound sales), marketing pagado, trabajo de campo, y otros canales, y lo comparas con los estándares de la industria, creo que la fórmula secreta de Ramp no es que hayamos encontrado un canal único donde invertimos de más o de menos. Lo que hemos hecho diferente es enfocarnos en hacer que todas esas inversiones estén muy impulsadas por tecnología y datos.
context: Lenny asks Sri to break down Ramp's growth channels into a pie chart format. Sri explains that while Ramp's channel distribution isn't dramatically different from industry benchmarks, their competitive advantage lies in how they execute these channels using technology and data. He describes how Ramp has built systems to make traditional growth channels like sales and paid marketing more efficient through engineering support and automation.
vocabulary_highlights: over-invested or under-invested, secret sauce, driven by technology and data

speaker: Sri Batchu
text: I think what works really well with Ramp is that we have the same shared goal, which is the pipeline driven and the payback period of the channel. It's unique to Ramp where the engineers feel ownership of the quota. They're not owning product metrics or what have you, they're obviously of course interim and input metrics that are important, but they really do feel accountable for the pipeline driven and the efficiency driven by that team.
text_ko: Ramp에서 정말 잘 맞는 건 우리 모두 같은 목표를 공유한다는 거예요 — 채널의 파이프라인 중심(pipeline-driven) 운영과 채널의 투자 회수 기간(payback period)이에요. 엔지니어들이 쿼터(quota)에 대해 주인의식을 느낀다는 건 Ramp만의 독특한 점이에요. 제품 지표(product metrics)를 직접 관리하진 않지만, 중간 지표(interim metrics)나 투입 지표(input metrics) 같은 것들이 중요하다는 건 당연해요. 그럼에도 불구하고 이들은 파이프라인 중심(pipeline-driven)의 성과와 팀이 만들어내는 효율성(efficiency)에 대해 진짜 책임감을 느껴요.
text_zh: 我觉得和Ramp合作特别顺的地方就是，我们目标很一致，都是奔着渠道的pipeline(销售漏斗)和回本周期去的。Ramp比较特别的是，他们的工程师对quota(销售指标)特别有主人翁意识。他们不是只盯着产品数据啊什么的，当然那些过程指标和输入指标肯定也重要，但他们确实会为pipeline的效果和团队的效率负责任。
text_es: Creo que lo que funciona muy bien con Ramp es que tenemos el mismo objetivo en común, que es el pipeline generado y el período de retorno de la inversión del canal. Es algo único de Ramp donde los ingenieros sienten que son dueños de la cuota. No están enfocados en métricas de producto ni nada por el estilo - obviamente hay métricas intermedias y de entrada que son importantes - pero realmente se sienten responsables del pipeline generado y de la eficiencia que logra ese equipo.
context: Lenny asks about Ramp's growth engineering team structure and how their goals are measured. Sri explains that their growth engineering team has a unique accountability system where engineers don't just focus on typical product metrics, but actually feel ownership for sales quotas and pipeline generation. This alignment ensures engineers work on projects that directly impact business outcomes rather than just technical metrics.
vocabulary_highlights: payback period, feel ownership of the quota, what have you, interim and input metrics

speaker: Sri Batchu
text: What you see internally is what I'll say is razor-sharp focus on reducing cycle time and bias to action and how do we reduce cycle time. I think it's basically the core of it culturally to me is getting people to think about smaller units of time for decision making. It seems obvious but I think you really have to reinforce it culturally.
text_ko: 사내에서 보이는 건, 제 말로 하자면 사이클 타임(cycle time)을 줄이는 데 대한 정말 날카로운 집중과 행동 편향(bias to action), 그리고 '사이클 타임을 어떻게 줄일지'에 대한 고민이에요. 제게 문화적으로 가장 핵심은 사람들이 의사결정을 더 짧은 시간 단위로 생각하게 만드는 거예요. 겉으로는 당연해 보이지만, 실제로는 그걸 조직 문화로 계속해서 강화해야 해요.
text_zh: 从内部来看，我觉得就是要超级专注地缩短决策周期(cycle time)，偏向于赶紧行动起来，怎么把这个周期时间给压缩下来。我觉得从文化上来说，核心就是要让大家习惯用更短的时间单位去做决策。听起来挺简单的，但你真得在文化层面不断强化这一点。
text_es: Lo que vemos internamente es lo que yo llamaría un enfoque súper preciso en reducir los tiempos de ciclo y esa tendencia hacia la acción - ¿cómo acortamos los plazos? Creo que básicamente el núcleo cultural para mí es lograr que la gente piense en períodos más cortos para tomar decisiones. Parece obvio, pero realmente tienes que reforzarlo como parte de la cultura.
context: Lenny asks Sri to explain what Ramp's legendary velocity culture actually looks and feels like from the inside. Sri describes how Ramp maintains unprecedented product velocity by focusing intensely on reducing cycle time and creating a bias toward action. He emphasizes that the key is getting people to think in smaller time units for decision-making, though this cultural approach requires constant reinforcement.
vocabulary_highlights: razor-sharp focus, bias to action, cycle time, reinforce it culturally

speaker: Sri Batchu
text: I think design of the team, people often... I think it's a red herring about team structure and team design and what's the right one, et cetera. I think most of that is irrelevant. What actually matters is culture and rituals and cadences rather than the team itself.
text_ko: 저는 팀 구조(team structure)나 팀 디자인(team design), 어떤 게 옳은지 따지는 건 오히려 본질을 흐리는 얘기라고 생각해요. 실제로 중요한 건 팀 자체가 아니라 문화와 의식(rituals), 그리고 운영 리듬(cadences)이에요.
text_zh: 我觉得团队设计这个事儿，大家经常... 我觉得纠结团队架构啊、团队设计啊、什么样的结构最好啊这些，其实都是在转移注意力。我觉得这些大部分都不重要。真正重要的是文化、仪式感和节奏，而不是团队本身。
text_es: Mira, creo que el diseño de equipos, la gente muchas veces... pienso que es una distracción todo eso de la estructura del equipo y el diseño y cuál es el correcto, etcétera. Creo que la mayoría de eso no importa realmente. Lo que de verdad cuenta es la cultura y los rituales y las dinámicas (cadences) más que el equipo en sí.
context: Lenny asks Sri about his learnings on building repeatable growth engines and growth teams. Sri argues that most discussions about growth team structure and design are distractions from what really matters. He believes that culture, rituals, and cadences are far more important than the specific team composition or organizational structure when building effective growth engines.
vocabulary_highlights: red herring, rituals and cadences

speaker: Sri Batchu
text: I do think there's actually a general path that most B2B companies take and should take. My view is you start off with founder-led sales, the early team needs to know how to actually sell. Then you hire your first couple of salespeople, then you start some very low cost targeted marketing efforts. So whether it's content, community, small scale events, and then PR, after all of that is when you start paid and brand effort and then SEO probably start around the same time that you start paid marketing efforts.
text_ko: 저는 대부분의 B2B 회사들이 따라야 할 일반적인 경로가 있다고 생각해요. 제 생각에는 처음에는 창립자가 직접 판매를 하고, 초기 팀이 실제로 판매하는 방법을 알아야 해요. 그 다음에 첫 몇 명의 영업직원을 채용하고, 아주 저렴한 타겟 마케팅을 시작해야 해요. 콘텐츠, 커뮤니티, 소규모 이벤트 같은 것들이요. 그리고 PR을 진행한 후에야 유료 마케팅과 브랜드 노력을 시작하고, SEO도 아마 유료 마케팅을 시작할 때쯤에 함께 시작할 거예요.
text_zh: 我觉得大部分B2B公司其实都有一个通用的发展路径，也应该这样走。我的看法是，一开始肯定是创始人自己做销售，早期团队得知道怎么卖东西。然后你招几个销售，接着开始搞一些低成本的精准营销，比如做内容、建社群、办点小活动，再做做PR。等这些都搞定了，再开始投付费广告和品牌推广，SEO的话差不多和付费推广同时开始就行。
text_es: Creo que sí hay un camino general que la mayoría de las empresas B2B siguen y deberían seguir. Mi punto de vista es que empiezas con ventas lideradas por el fundador, el equipo inicial necesita saber cómo vender de verdad. Después contratas a tus primeros vendedores, luego arrancas con esfuerzos de marketing muy económicos y bien dirigidos. O sea, ya sea contenido, comunidad, eventos pequeños, y después relaciones públicas. Después de todo eso es cuando empiezas con los esfuerzos pagados y de marca, y luego el SEO probablemente lo inicias más o menos al mismo tiempo que arrancas con el marketing pagado.
context: Lenny asks Sri about his opinion on how to sequence different growth channels for B2B companies. Sri outlines a specific progression that he believes most B2B companies should follow, starting with founder-led sales and gradually adding more expensive and scalable channels. His reasoning is that channels become more expensive as you progress but also more effective as you learn about your customers.
vocabulary_highlights: founder-led sales, low cost targeted marketing efforts, small scale events
topics: Growth & Marketing, Starting a Company, Strategy & Planning

speaker: Sri Batchu
text: Growth experiments in my history are typically 30%-ish success rate. So the vast majority of things that you try don't work. And so you want to create a culture where people aren't afraid to take risks and aren't afraid to fail. And for me, failure is not that you didn't drive revenue, failure is not learning.
text_ko: 제가 해온 성장 실험(growth experiments)은 보통 성공률(success rate)이 한 30% 정도였어요. 그래서 시도하는 것들 대부분은 잘 안 돼요. 사람들이 위험을 감수하고 실패하는 걸 두려워하지 않는 문화를 만들어야 해요. 제게 실패란 수익을 못 냈다는 게 아니라, 그로부터 배우지 못한 거예요.
text_zh: 我做过的增长实验(growth experiments)成功率一般也就30%左右。也就是说，你尝试的大部分东西都不会成功。所以你得营造一种文化，让大家不怕冒险，不怕失败。在我看来，失败不是说你没带来收入，失败是你什么都没学到。
text_es: En mi experiencia, los experimentos de crecimiento suelen tener una tasa de éxito de alrededor del 30%. O sea, la gran mayoría de las cosas que pruebas no funcionan. Por eso necesitas crear una cultura donde la gente no tenga miedo de arriesgarse ni de fallar. Para mí, fallar no es que no generes ingresos, fallar es no aprender nada.
context: Lenny asks Sri to explain his concept of failing conclusively rather than just failing fast in experiments. Sri explains that most growth experiments fail (around 70% failure rate), so it's crucial to create a culture where people aren't afraid to take risks. He redefines failure - it's not about missing revenue targets, but about failing to learn from the experiment, which is why designing tests properly is essential.
vocabulary_highlights: 30%-ish success rate, vast majority, aren't afraid to take risks

speaker: Aarthi Ramamurthy
speaker_expertise: Product Management, Community Building, Growth Strategy
text: Well, I think it's also very personal to our context and our upbringing. For us, Sriram and I came from a fairly middle class family in India, this city in India that most people here won't probably know. And we grew up really liking computers but didn't have access to a computer for a longest time. In both our cases, our parents bought us our first computers after saving money for it and it was a hard thing.
text_ko: 음, 제겐 이건 저희 맥락과 성장 배경에 관한 아주 개인적인 얘기이기도 해요. 스리람과 저는 인도에서 비교적 중산층 가정에서 자랐는데, 저희가 자란 도시는 여기 계신 분들 대부분이 아마 잘 모를 거예요. 어렸을 때 저희는 컴퓨터를 정말 좋아했지만 오랫동안 컴퓨터를 접할 수 없었어요. 저희 둘 다 부모님이 돈을 모아 첫 컴퓨터를 사주셨는데, 그게 정말 쉬운 일이 아니었어요.
text_zh: 我觉得这跟我们自己的成长背景很有关系。我和Sriram都出生在印度的中产家庭，来自一个可能大家都没听说过的印度小城市。我们从小就特别喜欢电脑，但很长时间都碰不到电脑。我们俩的情况都一样，父母为了给我们买第一台电脑，攒了很久的钱，真的挺不容易的。
text_es: Bueno, creo que también es muy personal según nuestro contexto y cómo nos criaron. En nuestro caso, Sriram y yo venimos de una familia de clase media en la India, de una ciudad que probablemente la mayoría aquí no conoce. Crecimos con muchas ganas de tener computadoras pero no tuvimos acceso a una por muchísimo tiempo. En los dos casos, nuestros papás nos compraron nuestras primeras computadoras después de ahorrar dinero para eso, y fue algo muy difícil para ellos.
context: Lenny asks Aarthi and Sriram about their techno-optimism movement and why it's important to them. Aarthi explains their personal background - growing up middle-class in India without easy access to computers, then eventually getting their first computers after their parents saved money. She's setting up the foundation for why technology has been so transformative in their lives and why they're advocates for tech's positive impact.
vocabulary_highlights: fairly middle class, won't probably know, for a longest time, it was a hard thing

speaker: Aarthi Ramamurthy
speaker_expertise: Product Management, Community Building, Growth Strategy
text: Our first jobs were at Microsoft, we built developer tools and platforms. If you were in our shoes, you would feel the same way too. Tech has given us so much. And so for us to come here all the way from India, through multiple cities, we lived in Seattle and then here, the Bay Area, I've started tech companies, it is a bit frustrating to see the other viewpoint because you can see how much it has uplifted people, careers, lives, but also just from what we've been able to work on, what we've seen our friends work on and ship and put out there, it has dramatically moved the needle.
text_ko: 저희 첫 직장은 마이크로소프트였고, 개발자 도구와 플랫폼(developer tools and platforms)을 만들었어요. 여러분이 우리 입장이라면 아마 같은 기분을 느끼실 거예요. 기술(tech)이 우리에게 정말 많은 것을 주었어요. 저희는 인도에서 출발해 여러 도시를 거쳐 여기까지 왔고, 시애틀에 살다가 지금은 베이 에어리어에 있죠. 저는 여기서 테크 회사들(tech companies)을 창업하기도 했어요. 그래서 다른 관점을 보는 건 좀 답답해요. 얼마나 많은 사람들의 삶과 커리어를 끌어올렸는지 뻔히 보이니까요. 저희가 직접 해온 일들이나 친구들이 만들어서 출시한 것들만 봐도 영향력이 엄청났어요.
text_zh: 我们的第一份工作都是在微软，做开发工具和平台。如果你站在我们的角度，你也会有同样的感受。科技给了我们太多太多。我们从印度一路走来，辗转多个城市，在西雅图住过，现在又到了湾区，我也创办过科技公司，所以看到另一种观点时确实有点憋屈，因为你能亲眼看到科技是怎么改变人们的生活、事业和人生轨迹的。不光是我们自己做的项目，还有朋友们开发和推出的产品，真的是带来了翻天覆地的变化。
text_es: Nuestros primeros trabajos fueron en Microsoft, desarrollamos herramientas y plataformas para programadores. Si estuvieras en nuestro lugar, sentirías lo mismo. La tecnología nos ha dado muchísimo. Y para nosotros, que vinimos desde la India, pasando por varias ciudades, vivimos en Seattle y después aquí, en el Área de la Bahía, he fundado empresas de tech, es un poco frustrante ver el otro punto de vista porque puedes ver cómo ha transformado vidas, carreras profesionales, pero también por todo lo que hemos podido desarrollar, lo que hemos visto que nuestros amigos desarrollan y lanzan al mercado, realmente ha marcado una diferencia enorme.
context: Aarthi continues explaining why she and Sriram are techno-optimists. She describes their journey from India to working at Microsoft, then moving through Seattle to Silicon Valley where she started companies. She argues that technology has been transformative for their lives and careers, and expresses frustration with critics of tech because she's witnessed firsthand how technology uplifts people and creates opportunities.
vocabulary_highlights: uplifted people, dramatically moved the needle

speaker: Aarthi Ramamurthy
speaker_expertise: Product Management, Community Building, Growth Strategy
text: Most of my career I was like, 'Yeah, of course that makes sense, that's kind of what you do.' But I've come to realize that that is just not true and this might be a controversial opinion, but you have to get out there and build your own brand. You have to figure out what you stand for, what your core values are, what you believe in, what you think you want to do, what your next career trajectory is going to look like. All of that is just up to you.
text_ko: 제 경력의 대부분 동안은 '그게 당연하지, 그런 게 하는 일이야'라고 생각했어요. 그런데 점점 그것이 사실이 아니라는 걸 알게 됐어요. 좀 논란이 될 수도 있지만, 직접 나서서 자기만의 브랜드(brand)를 만들어야 해요. 자신이 무엇을 지향하는지, 핵심 가치가 무엇인지, 무엇을 믿는지, 무엇을 하고 싶은지, 앞으로 커리어가 어떻게 전개될지를 스스로 찾아 정해야 해요. 그 모든 건 결국 본인에게 달려 있어요.
text_zh: 我职业生涯的大部分时间都觉得，"对啊，这不是很正常吗，大家不都是这么做的嘛。"但后来我才意识到根本不是这回事儿。这话可能有点争议，但你必须得主动出击，打造自己的个人品牌(personal brand)。你得搞清楚自己代表什么，核心价值观是什么，信念是什么，想做什么，下一步的职业发展轨迹会是什么样。这些都得靠你自己。
text_es: Durante la mayor parte de mi carrera pensaba: "Claro, eso tiene sentido, es lo que uno hace normalmente." Pero me he dado cuenta de que eso simplemente no es cierto, y quizás sea una opinión polémica, pero tienes que salir ahí afuera y construir tu propia marca personal. Tienes que descubrir qué representas, cuáles son tus valores fundamentales, en qué crees, qué piensas que quieres hacer, cómo va a ser tu próxima trayectoria profesional. Todo eso depende únicamente de ti.
context: Lenny asks about building personal brands and networks. Aarthi explains how she used to believe the common corporate advice to 'just put your head down and do good work' - that products would speak for themselves. However, she's come to realize this approach doesn't work in practice. She argues that professionals need to actively build their personal brand and figure out their own career direction rather than expecting companies to do it for them.
vocabulary_highlights: controversial opinion, get out there, career trajectory

speaker: Aarthi Ramamurthy
speaker_expertise: Product Management, Community Building, Growth Strategy
text: And I think building a personal brand is looked down upon so much that people think of it as a dirty word. It's like, 'No, you can't do that.' 'Oh, look at this person who's branding themselves,' kind of thing. But I almost see it as what distinguishes you from everybody else and that is not so much saying something that you're not good at or touting yourself more, it's really about highlighting, 'I'm really good at this thing and I want to talk about this thing and I want to do videos about it or write about it or tweet about it.'
text_ko: 제 생각엔 개인 브랜드(personal brand)를 만드는 걸 사람들이 너무 폄하해서 마치 부정적인 말, 꺼리는 말처럼 여기는 것 같아요. '아니야, 그건 하면 안 돼'라든가 '저 사람 자기 브랜딩(branding) 하는 것 봐라' 이런 식이죠. 근데 저는 오히려 그게 남들과 차별되는 지점이라고 봐요. 개인 브랜딩이란 못하는 걸 부풀리거나 자랑을 더 하려는 게 아니라, '나는 이걸 정말 잘해요. 이 주제로 얘기하고 싶고, 영상도 만들고 글도 쓰고 트윗도 하고 싶다'는 걸 강조하는 거예요.
text_zh: 我觉得打造个人品牌(personal brand)被大家看得太负面了，好像成了什么见不得人的词儿。大家都会说"不行，你不能这么干"，"你看这人，又在包装自己"，就是这种感觉。但我觉得这其实就是让你从众人中脱颖而出的东西，也不是说要吹嘘自己不擅长的事儿，或者过度自我推销，而是要突出"我在这方面确实很厉害，我想聊这个话题，我想做视频讲这个，或者写文章，发推特什么的"。
text_es: Y creo que construir una marca personal está tan mal visto que la gente lo ve como algo sucio. Es como "No, eso no se puede hacer" o "Ay, mira a este que se está promocionando", ¿sabes? Pero yo más bien lo veo como lo que te diferencia de todos los demás, y no se trata tanto de decir algo en lo que no eres bueno o presumir de más, sino realmente de destacar: "Soy muy bueno en esto y quiero hablar de esto y quiero hacer videos al respecto o escribir sobre ello o tuitearlo."
context: Aarthi continues her response about personal branding. She addresses the negative perception many people have of personal branding, noting that it's often seen as a 'dirty word' or something unprofessional. She reframes personal branding not as boastful self-promotion, but as authentically highlighting your genuine strengths and expertise through various content channels like videos, writing, or social media.
vocabulary_highlights: dirty word, touting yourself, distinguishes you from everybody else

speaker: Sriram Krishnan
speaker_expertise: Product Strategy, Growth Strategy, Community Building
text: You do this, you do two coffees a week and literally just ask me two hours a week, everyone has two hours a week, it'll start compounding over overtime and time. And then as the years go by, you keep in touch with the people you used to work with you, these folks will go to other places, five years, six years go by, you start in your mid-20s or late 20s and you know hundreds of people all over.
text_ko: 이렇게 해보세요. 일주일에 커피 약속을 두 번 잡고, 그냥 주당 두 시간만 저한테 물어보면 돼요. 누구에게나 일주일에 두 시간은 있잖아요. 그러면 시간이 지날수록 복리 효과(compounding)처럼 쌓이기 시작해요. 그리고 몇 년이 지나 같이 일했던 사람들과 계속 연락을 유지하면, 그 사람들이 다른 곳으로 옮기기도 하고, 5년, 6년이 지나면 20대 중반이나 후반에 시작했을 때 이미 여러 곳에 아는 사람이 수백 명이 돼요.
text_zh: 你就这么做，每周约两次咖啡聊天，就问我要两个小时，谁都能挤出两个小时吧，这样慢慢积累下去会有复利效应。然后随着时间推移，你跟以前的同事保持联系，这些人会跳槽到其他地方，五六年过去了，你从二十多岁开始做起，到时候就认识好几百号人，遍布各个地方。
text_es: Mira, haces esto, te tomas dos cafés a la semana conmigo y literalmente me dedicas dos horas a la semana - todo el mundo tiene dos horas a la semana - y esto se va acumulando con el tiempo. Y entonces, conforme pasan los años, mantienes el contacto con la gente con la que trabajabas, esta gente se va a otros lados, pasan cinco, seis años, empiezas a los 25 o casi 30 y ya conoces a cientos de personas por todas partes.
context: Sriram is giving detailed advice on how to build a professional network. He's explaining a systematic approach where you consistently meet with two people per week for coffee - just investing two hours weekly. He emphasizes how this compounds over time, and as people move to different companies over the years, you build a network of hundreds of contacts across the industry. This is part of his broader framework for authentic relationship building.
vocabulary_highlights: start compounding over overtime, all over

speaker: Sriram Krishnan
speaker_expertise: Product Strategy, Growth Strategy, Community Building
text: The other key part is expecting nothing in return. And generally people are very good at reading other people and if you go and being like, 'Hey, I just want to meet you because I want a job or I'm here to network,' whatever that means, they don't want to meet you. Just go and be very curious about who they are and try and help them. And you'll be surprised wherever you start, within a year, two years, you'll know hundreds of people who you can tap into, so I think that is super powerful.
text_ko: 다른 핵심은 아무 대가도 바라지 않는 거예요. 그리고 보통 사람들은 상대 의도를 잘 알아봐요. '저는 일자리 때문에 만나고 싶어요'라든지 '네트워킹(networking)하러 왔어요'라고 하면 상대가 만나고 싶어하지 않아요. 그냥 가서 그 사람이 어떤 사람인지 진심으로 궁금해해 보세요. 그리고 도와줄 수 있는 게 있으면 도와주려고 해보세요. 어디서 시작하든 1년, 2년 안에 도움 받을 수 있는 수백 명의 사람들을 알게 돼서 깜짝 놀랄 거예요. 그래서 그게 정말 강력해요.
text_zh: 另一个关键点就是不要指望别人回报你什么。一般来说，大家都很会看人，如果你过去就是那种"嘿，我想认识你是因为我想找工作"或者"我是来networking的"，不管这意味着什么吧，人家根本不想见你。你就去真心地对他们这个人感兴趣，想办法帮助他们。你会发现很神奇，不管你从哪儿开始，一年两年内，你就能认识几百号人，需要的时候都能联系上，我觉得这个力量真的很强大。
text_es: La otra parte clave es no esperar nada a cambio. Y en general la gente es muy buena leyendo a otros, entonces si llegas con la actitud de "Oye, solo quiero conocerte porque quiero un trabajo" o "estoy aquí para hacer networking," como sea que le digas, no van a querer conocerte. Simplemente ve y ten mucha curiosidad genuina sobre quién son y trata de ayudarlos. Y te vas a sorprender - no importa dónde empieces, en un año, dos años, vas a conocer cientos de personas a las que puedes recurrir, así que creo que eso es súper poderoso.
context: Sriram continues his networking advice, emphasizing the importance of authentic relationship building. He warns against transactional approaches where you're obviously seeking something (like a job), noting that people can easily detect these motives. Instead, he advocates for genuine curiosity about others and a willingness to help them. He promises that this authentic approach will build a valuable network you can eventually 'tap into' for opportunities.
vocabulary_highlights: expecting nothing in return, tap into

speaker: Sriram Krishnan
speaker_expertise: Product Strategy, Growth Strategy, Community Building
text: Both Aarthi and I at different points in our career have gotten feedback in our job saying, 'Oh, with Sriram and Aarthi, it's brand build too much, et cetera.' I have learned that that is terrible feedback and to totally ignore that and if anybody hears anything like that, just totally ignore that. The things that work well for me and a lot of others is putting yourself out there and that can be anything.
text_ko: 아르티와 저는 커리어의 각기 다른 시점에서 회사에서 '스리람(Sriram)이나 아르티는 브랜드 구축(brand build)을 너무 많이 한다'라는 피드백을 받은 적이 있어요. 저는 그게 정말 형편없는 피드백이라는 걸 배웠고, 그런 얘기를 들으면 그냥 완전히 무시하라고 배웠어요. 저와 많은 사람들에게 잘 통하는 건 자신을 적극적으로 드러내는 것(putting yourself out there)인데, 그 방법은 뭐든 될 수 있어요.
text_zh: 我和Aarthi在职业生涯的不同阶段都收到过这样的反馈，说什么"Sriram和Aarthi太爱搞个人品牌了"之类的。我现在明白了，这种反馈简直就是废话，完全不用理会。如果有人听到类似的话，直接忽略就行了。对我和很多人来说，真正有用的就是要敢于表现自己，这可以是任何形式。
text_es: Tanto Aarthi como yo, en diferentes momentos de nuestras carreras, hemos recibido comentarios en el trabajo del tipo "Ay, es que Sriram y Aarthi se enfocan demasiado en construir su marca personal, y todo eso." He aprendido que ese tipo de feedback es pésimo y hay que ignorarlo completamente, y si alguien escucha algo así, que lo ignore totalmente. Lo que me funciona bien a mí y a muchos otros es darse a conocer (putting yourself out there), y eso puede ser cualquier cosa.
context: Sriram is discussing personal branding and shares that both he and Aarthi have received negative feedback at work for building their personal brands too much. He strongly advises people to ignore this type of feedback, calling it 'terrible feedback.' He argues that 'putting yourself out there' through various forms of content creation and personal branding is actually beneficial for career success, contrary to what some managers might say.
vocabulary_highlights: terrible feedback, putting yourself out there, et cetera

speaker: Sriram Krishnan
speaker_expertise: Product Strategy, Growth Strategy, Community Building
text: You'd be amazed how often somebody just have a random great Twitter thread with no followers and somebody super interesting will email them and that leads to amazing things happening, it encourages serendipity. So over the years, I wish I had listened less to people who said I should not do this and listened more to the people who said I should do this more.
text_ko: 생각보다 자주 팔로워(followers)가 거의 없는 사람이 우연히 멋진 트위터(Twitter) 쓰레드(thread)를 올리면, 굉장히 흥미로운 사람이 그 사람에게 이메일을 보내고 그게 놀라운 일로 이어지곤 해요. 그게 우연한 행운(serendipity)을 만들어줘요. 그래서 지난 몇 년을 돌이켜보면, '이걸 하지 마'라고 했던 사람들 말은 좀 덜 들을 걸 그랬고, '이걸 더 해'라고 했던 사람들 말은 더 들었어야 했어요.
text_zh: 你会惊讶地发现，经常有人发了个很棒的推特串(Twitter thread)，明明没什么粉丝，结果就有超有意思的人给他们发邮件，然后就促成了很多amazing的事情，这就是在创造偶然的机会嘛。所以这些年下来，我真希望当初少听那些劝我别这么做的人的话，多听听那些鼓励我更多去做的人。
text_es: Te sorprendería la cantidad de veces que alguien simplemente publica un hilo genial en Twitter sin tener seguidores y de repente una persona súper interesante le manda un email, y eso termina generando cosas increíbles. Es como que facilita esas casualidades afortunadas. Así que después de todos estos años, ojalá hubiera hecho menos caso a la gente que me decía que no debería hacer esto y hubiera escuchado más a los que me decían que tenía que hacerlo más seguido.
context: Sriram continues explaining the benefits of creating content and building a personal brand online. He describes how putting yourself out there acts like a 'Bat-Signal' that attracts interesting opportunities and people. He gives an example of how even someone with no followers can create great content that gets noticed by influential people, leading to unexpected opportunities. This is part of his argument for why people should ignore advice against personal branding.
vocabulary_highlights: encourages serendipity, amazing things happening

speaker: Aarthi Ramamurthy
speaker_expertise: Product Management, Community Building, Growth Strategy
text: Find the niche, start really small and find the niche. I think oftentimes I've seen other startup founders and I invest and advise in a lot of early stage companies. I went through Y Combinator, so I go back to YC as much as I can and go help out folks. But oftentimes I'll see people starting companies or founders coming in and being like, 'I'm going to build this product that is going to cater to this community. I'm going to build this world's largest community off this kind of thing,' and it almost starts at this super scaled version and then they set themselves up for failure.
text_ko: 틈새 시장을 찾아야 해요. 정말 작게 시작해서 그 틈새를 공략해요. 저는 다른 스타트업 창업자들을 자주 보는데, 초기 단계 회사들에 많이 투자하고 조언해요. 와이컴비네이터(Y Combinator)를 거쳐서 가능한 한 자주 YC에 가서 사람들을 도와주고요. 그런데 종종 창업자들이 와서 "이 커뮤니티를 위한 제품을 만들고, 이걸로 세계에서 가장 큰 커뮤니티를 만들겠다"라고 말해요. 거의 처음부터 지나치게 확장된 버전으로 시작하다 보니 스스로 실패를 불러오더라고요.
text_zh: 要找到细分市场，从特别小的地方开始，先找准这个细分领域。我经常看到其他创业者——我投资和指导了很多早期公司，我自己也是从Y Combinator出来的，所以经常回YC帮忙——但我常常看到有人创业或者创始人过来就说，"我要做个产品服务这个群体，我要围绕这个东西打造全世界最大的社区"，一上来就想做得特别大，结果往往把自己给坑了。
text_es: Encuentra tu nicho, empieza súper pequeño y encuentra ese nicho. Creo que muchas veces he visto a otros fundadores de startups - y yo invierto y asesoro en muchas empresas que están empezando - pasé por Y Combinator, entonces regreso a YC siempre que puedo para echar una mano. Pero muchas veces veo gente que está arrancando empresas o fundadores que llegan y dicen, 'Voy a crear este producto que va a servir a esta comunidad. Voy a construir la comunidad más grande del mundo de este tipo de cosa,' y casi empiezan con esta versión súper escalada y ahí mismo se están preparando para el fracaso.
context: Lenny asks Aarthi about the key things to get right when building a new community. Aarthi, drawing from her experience building community products at Facebook and Clubhouse, plus her work as an investor and advisor to early-stage companies, emphasizes starting small and finding a specific niche. She criticizes founders who try to build massive, scaled communities from the beginning, arguing this approach sets them up for failure rather than finding focused product-market fit first.
vocabulary_highlights: find the niche, cater to this community, super scaled version, set themselves up for failure
topics: Starting a Company, Strategy & Planning, Growth & Marketing

speaker: Aarthi Ramamurthy
speaker_expertise: Product Management, Community Building, Growth Strategy
text: You're almost better off doing these small, niche, non-scalable things to go find these oddball set of people who are doing this, who are really interested in this one thing and kind of scale from there and grow from there. And I think that's one big thing that when you're starting to build a community, don't start to build this super scaled community. Start with few people who are passionate about a particular problem and want to get together kind of thing.
text_ko: 오히려 작고 틈새적이고 확장 불가능한(non-scalable) 일들을 먼저 해보는 편이 더 나을 때가 많아요. 그런 식으로 이 한 가지에 정말 관심 있는, 조금 독특한 소수의 사람들을 찾아서 거기서부터 조금씩 스케일(scale)해 나가고 성장하면 돼요. 커뮤니티를 만들기 시작할 때 한 가지 중요한 건, 처음부터 엄청나게 규모를 키우려고 하지 말라는 거예요. 특정 문제에 열정을 가진 몇몇 사람들부터 모아 시작하는 게 훨씬 좋아요.
text_zh: 你最好是先做一些小众的、非标准化的事情，去找到那些真正对某个特定领域感兴趣的人，然后再从那里慢慢做大。我觉得在搭建社群的时候，千万别一上来就想着做成超大规模的社群。你得先找到几个对某个问题特别有热情、想要聚在一起交流的人开始做起。
text_es: Es casi mejor que te enfoques en cosas pequeñas, muy específicas, que no se puedan escalar masivamente para encontrar a esa gente medio rara que está metida en esto, que realmente le apasiona este tema en particular, y desde ahí empezar a crecer. Y creo que eso es algo clave cuando estás empezando a construir una comunidad: no trates de armar una súper comunidad escalable desde el inicio. Empieza con poca gente que esté apasionada por un problema específico y que quiera juntarse, ¿sabes?
context: Aarthi continues her advice on community building. She advocates for deliberately doing 'non-scalable things' initially to find a core group of passionate users - what she calls an 'oddball set of people' who are deeply interested in a specific problem or topic. This is part of her broader framework that successful communities should start small and niche before attempting to scale, rather than trying to build massive communities from day one.
vocabulary_highlights: non-scalable things, oddball set of people, scale from there

speaker: Stewart Butterfield
speaker_expertise: B2B SaaS, User Experience, Product Strategy
text: The most basic example I can think of is let's say you're making a hammer, and on that bottom axis, it's now quality, and if the hammer has a handle that breaks with any impact, then is totally useless. And if you make it a little bit stronger, it's still pretty useless and it's like junk, junk, junk, junk, junk. Okay, good, great. Then it doesn't matter anymore.
text_ko: 가장 기본적인 예로 망치를 만든다고 해볼게요. 그 하단 축(bottom axis)을 ‘품질’로 보면, 손잡이가 조금만 충격을 받아도 부러지는 망치는 완전히 쓸모없어요. 조금 더 튼튼하게 만든다고 해도 여전히 별로고, 그냥 쓰레기예요, 쓰레기... 알겠죠? 그러면 더 이상 상관없어요.
text_zh: 我能想到的最简单的例子就是，比如说你在做锤子，底下这个轴代表质量，如果锤子的把手一碰就断，那就完全没用。你稍微做结实一点，还是很垃圾，就是垃圾、垃圾、垃圾、垃圾、垃圾。然后突然就变成，好，很好，非常好。再往上就没什么区别了。
text_es: El ejemplo más básico que se me ocurre es digamos que estás fabricando un martillo, y en ese eje inferior tienes la calidad, y si el martillo tiene un mango que se rompe con cualquier golpe, pues es totalmente inútil. Y si lo haces un poquito más resistente, sigue siendo bastante inútil y es como basura, basura, basura, basura, basura. Vale, bien, genial. Después ya no importa más.
context: Lenny asks Stewart about utility curves, a concept that came up frequently when talking to people who worked with him. Stewart explains that utility curves are S-shaped curves where the horizontal axis represents cost or effort, and the vertical axis represents value or convenience. He uses the hammer example to illustrate how initial investment yields little value until you reach a threshold where it becomes useful, after which additional investment provides diminishing returns.
vocabulary_highlights: bottom axis, totally useless, junk, junk, junk

speaker: Stewart Butterfield
speaker_expertise: B2B SaaS, User Experience, Product Strategy
text: I would tell the story at Slack over and over again. It actually made it part of the new hire welcome. Your failure to really be considerate and exercise this courtesy and really be empathic about other people's experience is an advantage that you can create a critical advantage.
text_ko: 슬랙에서는 그 이야기를 계속해서 반복했어요. 실제로 그걸 신입 환영 프로그램(new hire welcome)의 일부로 넣었죠. 다른 사람들이 진정으로 배려하거나 타인의 경험에 공감(empathic)하지 못하는 건 오히려 기회예요. 그걸 잘 활용하면 결정적인 이점(critical advantage)을 만들 수 있어요.
text_zh: 我在Slack的时候会反复讲这个故事，后来甚至把它加到了新员工入职培训里。你要是不够体贴，不懂得换位思考，不能真正理解别人的感受和经历，这其实是你可以创造的一个关键优势。
text_es: Yo contaba esta historia en Slack una y otra vez. De hecho, terminó siendo parte de la bienvenida para los nuevos empleados. Si no logras ser realmente considerado y tener esta cortesía, si no eres empático con la experiencia de los demás, pierdes la oportunidad de crear una ventaja competitiva crucial.
context: Lenny asks Stewart about taste and craft in product development. Stewart shares the 'umbrella story' from Vancouver, where he and a colleague noticed how few people would tilt their umbrellas to avoid poking others in crowded sidewalks. This became a metaphor at Slack for being considerate of user experience - 'tilt your umbrella' became company slang for thinking about how your actions affect others.
vocabulary_highlights: new hire welcome, be considerate, exercise this courtesy, be empathic, create a critical advantage

speaker: Stewart Butterfield
speaker_expertise: B2B SaaS, User Experience, Product Strategy
text: So we came up with what was called the shouty rooster, and internally we said, 'Don't be a cock.' But we didn't obviously say that publicly when you @everyone, a little rooster would pop up and it would have you sound waves coming out of its mouth and being really obnoxious and say, 'Hey, this is going to cause a notification for 147 people in eight different time zones. Are you sure you want to send this message with the @everyone?'
text_ko: 그래서 저희는 '소리지르는 수탉(shouty rooster)'이라는 걸 만들었고, 내부적으로는 '건방지게 굴지 말자'고 했어요. 물론 그걸 공개적으로 말하진 않았고요. 누군가 @everyone(@everyone)을 쓰면 작은 수탉 아이콘이 팝업하면서 입에서 소리파가 나오는 애니메이션으로 정말 거슬리게 등장해서, "이걸 보내면 8개 시간대에 걸쳐 147명에게 알림(notification)이 갑니다. @everyone으로 이 메시지를 보내시겠어요?"라고 뜨게 했어요.
text_zh: 所以我们就设计了一个叫"大嗓门公鸡"的功能，内部我们叫它"别当混蛋"。当然对外我们肯定不会这么说。当你要@所有人的时候，会弹出一只小公鸡，嘴巴里冒出声波，特别讨厌的样子，然后说："嘿，这条消息会给8个不同时区的147个人发通知。你确定要发这条@所有人的消息吗？"
text_es: Entonces se nos ocurrió lo que llamamos el gallo gritón (shouty rooster), y internamente decíamos "No seas gallina" - aunque obviamente no lo dijimos así públicamente. Cuando hacías @everyone, aparecía un gallito con ondas de sonido saliendo de su pico, súper molesto, que te decía: "Oye, esto va a mandar una notificación a 147 personas en ocho zonas horarias diferentes. ¿Estás seguro de que quieres enviar este mensaje con @everyone?"
context: Stewart is explaining examples of craft and thoughtful product design at Slack. He describes how they solved the problem of people overusing the @everyone feature, which would send notifications to all channel members. The 'shouty rooster' was a visual warning that appeared to make users think twice before notifying everyone, helping shape better communication culture within organizations.
vocabulary_highlights: shouty rooster, being really obnoxious, eight different time zones

speaker: Stewart Butterfield
speaker_expertise: B2B SaaS, User Experience, Product Strategy
text: It became an assumption that it should always be trying to remove friction when the challenge is really comprehension. If your software stops me and asks me to make a decision and I don't really understand it, you make me feel stupid. If people could get over the idea of reducing friction as a number of goal or reducing the number of clicks or taps to do something, and instead focus on how can I make this simple? How do I prevent people from having to think in order to use my software?
text_ko: 항상 마찰(friction)을 없애야 한다는 전제가 생겼는데, 실제 문제는 이해에 있는 경우가 많아요. 소프트웨어가 저를 멈춰 세우고 결정을 요구하는데 제가 그걸 잘 이해하지 못하면, 그건 저를 바보처럼 느끼게 해요. 사람들이 마찰(friction)을 줄이는 걸 목표로 삼거나 클릭(clicks)이나 탭(taps) 횟수만 줄이려는 집착에서 벗어나서, 대신 "이걸 어떻게 더 단순하게 만들까? 사람들이 내 소프트웨어를 쓰면서 굳이 생각하지 않게 하려면 어떻게 해야 할까?"에 집중하면 좋겠어요.
text_zh: 大家都觉得应该一直想着怎么减少摩擦，但其实真正的挑战是理解问题。如果你的软件突然跳出来让我做决定，而我根本搞不清楚是怎么回事，这就让我觉得自己很蠢。要是大家能不要老想着减少摩擦或者减少点击次数这些指标，而是专注于"我怎么能让这个东西变简单？怎么让用户不用动脑子就能用我的软件？"那就好了。
text_es: Se convirtió en algo que dábamos por hecho: que siempre había que eliminar la fricción, cuando en realidad el desafío está en la comprensión. Si tu software me detiene y me pide que tome una decisión y yo realmente no la entiendo, me haces sentir tonto. Si la gente pudiera dejar atrás esa idea de reducir la fricción como un objetivo numérico, o de reducir la cantidad de clics o toques para hacer algo, y en cambio se enfocara en: ¿cómo puedo hacer esto más simple? ¿Cómo evito que la gente tenga que pensar para usar mi software?
context: Lenny asks Stewart about his counterintuitive view that friction in products can actually be good. Stewart explains that many product teams obsess over reducing friction and clicks, but the real challenge is often comprehension - helping users understand what they're supposed to do. He argues that making users think or feel stupid is worse than having a few extra steps, and advocates for focusing on simplicity and clarity instead.
vocabulary_highlights: became an assumption, challenge is really comprehension, make me feel stupid, get over the idea, prevent people from having to think

speaker: Stewart Butterfield
speaker_expertise: B2B SaaS, User Experience, Product Strategy
text: The decision is about have you exhausted the possibilities? Creating the distance so that you can make an intellectual rational decision about it rather than an emotional decision is essential. And the reason I say you have to be coldly rational about it is because it's fucking humiliating.
text_ko: 결정은 '가능한 선택지를 다 써봤나?' 하는 거예요. 감정적으로 결정하지 않고 이성적으로 판단할 수 있도록 거리를 두는 게 중요해요. 제가 냉정하게 이성적으로 하라고 말하는 이유는 솔직히 그게 진짜 굴욕적이거든요.
text_zh: 这个决定的关键是，你有没有把所有可能性都试遍了？你得拉开距离，这样才能理性地、冷静地做决定，而不是凭感情用事，这一点特别重要。我之所以说必须得冷酷理性，是因为这事儿真的太他妈丢人了。
text_es: La decisión se trata de: ¿ya agotaste todas las posibilidades? Crear esa distancia para poder tomar una decisión racional e intelectual en lugar de una emocional es fundamental. Y la razón por la que digo que tienes que ser fríamente racional es porque es jodidamente humillante.
context: Lenny asks Stewart about pivoting, since he successfully pivoted both Flickr and Slack from failed video game companies. Stewart explains that the key question for founders considering a pivot is whether they've exhausted all reasonable possibilities for their current idea. He emphasizes the need to make rational rather than emotional decisions, acknowledging that pivoting is emotionally difficult because of the humiliation involved in admitting failure.
vocabulary_highlights: exhausted the possibilities, creating the distance, intellectual rational decision, coldly rational, fucking humiliating

speaker: Stewart Butterfield
speaker_expertise: B2B SaaS, User Experience, Product Strategy
text: At more than one company all hands, I made everyone in the company repeat this as a chant. In the long run, the measure of our success will be the amount of value that we create for customers, and you can put effort into demonstrating that you have created this value and stuff like that, but there's no substitute for actually having created it.
text_ko: 여러 회사의 올핸즈(all-hands) 미팅에서 저는 회사 사람들 모두에게 이 말을 구호처럼 외치게 했어요. 장기적으로 성공의 척도는 고객에게 우리가 만들어낸 가치의 크기예요. 그 가치를 증명하려고 애쓰거나 겉으로 보여주려 할 수는 있지만, 실제로 그 가치를 만들어낸 것만큼 대체할 수 있는 건 없어요.
text_zh: 在不止一次的全员大会上，我让公司所有人跟我一起喊这句话。从长远来看，衡量我们成功与否的标准就是我们为客户创造了多少价值，你可以花力气去证明你创造了这些价值什么的，但这些都比不上你真的创造出了价值。
text_es: En más de una reunión general de la empresa, hice que todos repitieran esto como un mantra. A la larga, lo que va a medir nuestro éxito será el valor real que creemos para nuestros clientes, y sí, puedes esforzarte en demostrar que has creado ese valor y todo eso, pero no hay nada que sustituya el haberlo creado de verdad.
context: Stewart is discussing his approach to generosity and ethical business practices. He shares the company mantra he made all Slack employees recite at company meetings, emphasizing that true business success comes from actually creating value for customers, not just appearing to do so. This philosophy guided many of Slack's customer-friendly policies and generous practices.
vocabulary_highlights: company all hands, repeat this as a chant, measure of our success, no substitute for actually having created it

speaker: Stewart Butterfield
speaker_expertise: B2B SaaS, User Experience, Product Strategy
text: So people are like calling meetings with their colleagues to preview the deck that they're going to show in the big meeting to get feedback on whether they should improve some of the slides. And that hyper-realistic work-like activity is superficially identical to work.
text_ko: 그래서 사람들은 동료들끼리 모여서 큰 미팅(big meeting)에서 보여줄 덱(deck)을 미리 돌려보면서, 슬라이드를 고칠지 말지 피드백(feedback)을 받아요. 그런데 그렇게 일처럼 아주 현실감 있게 벌어지는 활동(hyper-realistic work-like activity)은 겉으로 보면 실제 업무와 거의 똑같아 보여요.
text_zh: 所以大家都在跟同事开会，先预演一下要在大会上展示的PPT，听听大家的意见看哪些页面需要改进。这种超级真实的类似工作的活动，表面上看起来跟真正的工作一模一样。
text_es: Entonces la gente está convocando reuniones con sus colegas para revisar la presentación que van a mostrar en la reunión importante, para recibir comentarios sobre si deberían mejorar algunas diapositivas. Y esa actividad hiper-realista que parece trabajo es superficialmente idéntica al trabajo real.
context: Stewart explains his concept of 'hyper-realistic work-like activities' - when organizations have more people than valuable work to do, employees end up creating pseudo-work that looks like real work but doesn't add value. He describes how this happens when companies grow and hire more people but don't have enough genuinely important tasks for everyone to focus on.
vocabulary_highlights: preview the deck, hyper-realistic work-like activity, superficially identical to work

speaker: Tamar Yehoshua
speaker_expertise: Product Design, AI/ML Products, Team Building
text: Make sure you go somewhere where you have a good engineering partner. Because if you have great ideas of what to build but you can't get them built, then you go nowhere. So that has to be part of your evaluation criteria that you meet and value your engineering partner before you join. And then I think what's really important is that you're aligned. You understand your roles and responsibilities and where you're going to divide and conquer and where you're going to be aligned. You don't want any of this ... Like people in the organization, they ask mom, they asked dad and they got different opinions and playing one against the other. That doesn't work.
text_ko: 반드시 좋은 엔지니어링 파트너(engineering partner)가 있는 곳으로 가세요. 뭘 만들어야 할지 좋은 아이디어가 있어도 그걸 실제로 만들지 못하면 아무 진전이 없어요. 그래서 합류하기 전에 엔지니어링 파트너를 직접 만나보고 그들을 존중하고 함께 일할 수 있는지를 평가 기준에 꼭 넣으세요. 그리고 정말 중요한 건 방향성이 맞는다는 거예요. 서로의 역할과 책임(roles and responsibilities)을 분명히 이해하고, 어떤 부분을 누가 맡아 처리할지(divide and conquer)와 어디서 함께할지를 명확히 해야 해요. 조직에서 누구한테 물어보느냐에 따라 다른 답을 받고, 그걸로 사람들을 편가르기하듯 이용하는 방식은 잘 안 통해요.
text_zh: 一定要确保你找到一个靠谱的技术合作伙伴。因为你有再好的想法，如果做不出来，那就是白搭。所以在你加入之前，这必须是你考量的标准之一——要先了解和认可你的技术合伙人。然后我觉得特别重要的是，你们要步调一致。要清楚各自的职责分工，哪些事情分头干，哪些事情要统一行动。千万别出现那种...就像组织里的人，今天问妈妈，明天问爸爸，得到不同的答案，然后挑拨离间。这样肯定不行。
text_es: Asegúrate de ir a un lugar donde tengas un buen socio de ingeniería. Porque si tienes ideas geniales de qué construir pero no logras que se hagan realidad, no llegas a ningún lado. Entonces eso tiene que ser parte de tus criterios de evaluación: que conozcas y valores a tu socio de ingeniería antes de unirte. Y después creo que lo que es súper importante es que estén alineados. Que entiendan sus roles y responsabilidades, dónde van a dividirse las tareas y dónde van a trabajar juntos. No quieres nada de esto de... Como cuando la gente en la organización le pregunta a mamá, luego le pregunta a papá, obtienen opiniones diferentes y ponen a uno contra el otro. Eso no funciona.
context: Lenny asks Tamar about building stronger cross-functional relationships, especially between product managers and engineers. Tamar explains that having a strong engineering partnership is crucial for product success - great ideas mean nothing if they can't be executed. She emphasizes the importance of alignment between product and engineering leaders, where both parties understand their roles and responsibilities and don't undermine each other by giving conflicting direction to their teams.
vocabulary_highlights: evaluation criteria, divide and conquer, playing one against the other

speaker: Tamar Yehoshua
speaker_expertise: Product Design, AI/ML Products, Team Building
text: One of the things that I think is overlooked is do a really good job at whatever your job is at that point. People have a tendency ... Especially product managers are very ambitious and they want to get to the next level and they're always eyeing the next job, but you're not going to get the next job unless you do really well at the job that you're in. Knock it out of the park. However simple, however easy it may be to you, do a great job.
text_ko: 제가 간과된다고 생각하는 것 중 하나는, 그 순간 맡은 일을 정말 잘하는 거예요. 사람들은 특히 프로덕트 매니저(product managers)들이 야망이 커서 항상 다음 단계만 보고 다음 직책을 노리는 경향이 있어요. 그런데 지금 하는 일을 정말 잘하지 않으면 다음 자리를 못 잡아요. 지금 맡은 일을 기대 이상으로, 완전히 해내세요. 아무리 단순하고 쉬워 보여도 훌륭하게 해내는 게 중요해요.
text_zh: 我觉得大家容易忽略的一点就是，先把手头的工作做到位。很多人都有这个毛病……特别是产品经理(product manager)，野心都挺大，总想着升职加薪，眼睛老盯着下一个岗位，但问题是你现在这个活儿都没干好，凭什么给你升职？得先把现在的工作做得漂漂亮亮的。不管这事儿在你看来多简单多容易，都要做到最好。
text_es: Una de las cosas que creo que se pasa por alto es hacer un trabajo excelente en lo que sea que estés haciendo en ese momento. La gente tiene tendencia... Especialmente los product managers son muy ambiciosos y quieren llegar al siguiente nivel y siempre están mirando el próximo puesto, pero no vas a conseguir el siguiente trabajo si no haces muy bien el trabajo que tienes ahora. Tienes que romperla completamente. Por más simple que sea, por más fácil que te parezca, haz un trabajo increíble.
context: Lenny asks Tamar about the specific skills or habits that contributed most to her successful career. Tamar explains that one of the most overlooked but important factors is excelling at your current role rather than constantly focusing on the next promotion. She argues that ambitious product managers often make the mistake of always looking ahead instead of delivering exceptional results in their present position, which is actually the key to advancement.
vocabulary_highlights: knock it out of the park, eyeing the next job

speaker: Tamar Yehoshua
speaker_expertise: Product Design, AI/ML Products, Team Building
text: One of the things that I caution product managers about is that you don't want to be too overly reliant on metrics and you want to also have an intuition. You want product managers who understand intuitively their customers and their product and sometimes you'll make decisions because you just know it's the right thing to do because it feels right and it usually is right if you understand your product well enough.
text_ko: 제가 프로덕트 매니저(product managers)들에게 자주 주의시키는 것 중 하나는 지표(metrics)에만 지나치게 의존하지 말라는 거예요. 직관(intuition)도 있어야 해요. 고객과 제품을 직관적으로 이해하는 프로덕트 매니저가 필요하고, 때로는 그냥 옳게 느껴져서 결정을 내릴 때도 있는데, 제품을 충분히 이해하고 있으면 그런 선택이 보통 맞는 경우가 많아요.
text_zh: 我经常提醒产品经理的一点就是，不要过分依赖数据指标，还得有直觉。你要找那种对客户和产品有直觉的产品经理，有时候做决策就是凭感觉，觉得这么做是对的就去做，如果你对产品足够了解的话，这种感觉通常都是准的。
text_es: Una de las cosas sobre las que les advierto a los product managers es que no se pueden apoyar demasiado en las métricas nada más, también tienen que tener intuición. Necesitas product managers que entiendan de forma intuitiva a sus clientes y su producto, y a veces vas a tomar decisiones simplemente porque sabes que es lo correcto, porque lo sientes así, y por lo general sí es lo correcto si conoces tu producto lo suficientemente bien.
context: Lenny asks for an example of understanding people in product development. Tamar discusses the balance between data-driven decisions and product intuition. She explains that while metrics are important, product managers shouldn't rely on them exclusively - they need to develop intuitive understanding of their customers and products. This intuition, when properly developed through deep product knowledge, can guide correct decisions even when data might not provide clear direction.
vocabulary_highlights: overly reliant, intuitively

speaker: Tamar Yehoshua
speaker_expertise: Product Design, AI/ML Products, Team Building
text: I love working at well-run companies. It's more fun, your people are happier. I like running a well-run team, so I aspire to have a very well run team and to work at a well run company. But what I've seen is when a company isn't well run like IT isn't working, marketing is broken, there are not enough people in HR, there's a lot of turnover. All of these things I've seen that they're not correlated to the company being successful.
text_ko: 저는 잘 운영되는 회사에서 일하는 걸 정말 좋아해요. 일이 더 즐겁고 직원들도 더 행복하거든요. 저는 체계적으로 잘 돌아가는 팀을 이끄는 걸 좋아해서, 그런 팀을 만들고 그런 회사에서 일하는 걸 목표로 해요. 그런데 제가 본 바로는 회사가 제대로 운영되지 않을 때—예를 들어 정보기술(IT)이 안 돌아가거나 마케팅(marketing)에 문제가 있거나 인사(HR) 인력이 부족하거나 이직률이 높다든지—이런 문제들이 회사의 성공 여부와는 크게 상관없더라고요.
text_zh: 我特别喜欢在管理到位的公司工作，这样工作起来更有意思，团队里的人也更开心。我自己也喜欢带一支运转良好的团队，所以我的目标就是要有一个管理很棒的团队，也要在一个管理很棒的公司工作。但我发现的是，当一个公司管理不善的时候，比如IT系统老出问题，市场部一团糟，HR人手不够，员工流失率很高，我见过很多这种情况，但这些问题其实跟公司是否成功没有直接关系。
text_es: Me encanta trabajar en empresas que están bien organizadas. Es más divertido, la gente está más contenta. Me gusta dirigir un equipo que funcione bien, así que aspiro a tener un equipo súper bien organizado y trabajar en una empresa que esté bien llevada. Pero lo que he visto es que cuando una empresa no está bien manejada - como que TI no funciona, marketing está hecho un desastre, no hay suficiente gente en Recursos Humanos, hay mucha rotación de personal - todas estas cosas que he observado no tienen que ver con que la empresa sea exitosa.
context: Lenny asks about Tamar's insight that companies don't need to be well-run to win. Tamar explains this seemingly contrarian view by distinguishing between what makes companies pleasant to work at versus what makes them successful. She acknowledges preferring well-run organizations for personal satisfaction, but observes that operational dysfunction - like broken IT systems, poor marketing, inadequate HR, and high turnover - doesn't necessarily prevent business success, while she's also seen well-run companies that fail to grow.
vocabulary_highlights: aspire to, not correlated to

speaker: Tamar Yehoshua
speaker_expertise: Product Design, AI/ML Products, Team Building
text: Really recently I was talking to somebody in their twenties who was asking me for career advice. Should I be a product manager, et cetera. And I'm trying to put together my five-year plan and I said, 'I never had a five-year plan.' So to be clear, some people need that. That's the kind of people they are. They want the planning. I said, 'It's great if you want that, but I never had it.' And the person I was talking to just relaxed and they're like, 'Oh my God, that's so great to hear because I have no idea what I want to do in five years.' I'm like, 'I still have no idea what I want to do in five years. I've never had an idea what I want to do in five years.'
text_ko: 얼마 전에 20대인 분이랑 얘기했어요. 커리어 조언을 구하시더라고요. “프로덕트 매니저(product manager)를 할까, 뭐 이렇게…” 그리고 5년 플랜을 세우려고 하는데 어떻게 할지 고민한다고 해서 제가 말했어요. “저는 한 번도 5년 계획을 세워본 적이 없어요.” 분명히 말하면 어떤 사람들은 그게 필요해요. 그런 타입이고 계획 세우는 걸 좋아하죠. “그게 원하면 하는 게 좋아요, 근데 저는 그런 계획이 없었어요”라고 했더니 그분이 갑자기 마음이 편해지면서 “와, 그 말 들으니 진짜 좋네요. 저도 5년 후에 뭘 하고 싶은지 전혀 모르겠어요”라고 하더라고요. 그래서 저도 “저도 여전히 5년 후에 뭘 하고 싶은지 모르겠어요. 한 번도 그런 생각을 해본 적이 없어요”라고 했어요.
text_zh: 最近我跟一个二十多岁的人聊天，他问我职业建议。说是应该做产品经理(product manager)什么的。然后他说正在搞五年规划，我就说，'我从来没做过什么五年规划。'当然啊，有些人确实需要这个，这就是他们的性格，喜欢做规划。我说，'你要是喜欢做规划那挺好的，但我从来不做。'然后那个人一下子就放松了，说，'天哪，你这么说我心里踏实多了，因为我根本不知道五年后想干什么。'我说，'我现在还是不知道五年后想干什么呢。我从来就没想过五年后要干什么。'
text_es: Hace poquito estaba hablando con alguien de veintitantos que me pidió consejos profesionales. Que si debería ser product manager, y esas cosas. Y me dice, 'Estoy tratando de armar mi plan a cinco años' y le digo, 'Yo nunca tuve un plan a cinco años.' O sea, que quede claro, hay gente que lo necesita. Es su forma de ser. Les gusta planificar. Le dije, 'Está genial si es lo tuyo, pero yo nunca lo tuve.' Y la persona se relajó completamente y me dice, 'Ay, qué alivio escuchar eso porque no tengo ni idea de qué quiero hacer en cinco años.' Y le digo, 'Yo tampoco tengo ni idea de qué quiero hacer en cinco años. Nunca he tenido ni idea de qué quiero hacer en cinco años.'
context: Lenny asks about Tamar's belief that you don't need to plan your career. Tamar shares a recent conversation with someone in their twenties seeking career advice about becoming a product manager and creating a five-year plan. She reveals that she has never had a five-year career plan throughout her successful career, which immediately relieved the anxiety of the person she was advising. This challenges the conventional wisdom that successful careers require detailed long-term planning.
vocabulary_highlights: put together, just relaxed

speaker: Tamar Yehoshua
speaker_expertise: Product Design, AI/ML Products, Team Building
text: What I believe, and I've always believed is that you follow people. You learn the most from people. I don't look for domains. Some people have a domain, like I'm super interested in climate or whatever and they really want to work in that area and that's fine so maybe within that area. But you follow people who are the best at what they do. So it's not good enough to follow somebody who you like. You want to follow somebody who's either the best product thinker or the best engineer or the best salesperson. And so that you will learn the skill of how to be the best at that.
text_ko: 제가 늘 믿어온 건 사람을 따라가야 한다는 거예요. 사람한테서 가장 많이 배우거든요. 저는 도메인(domain)을 찾지 않아요. 어떤 사람들은 기후 같은 특정 분야에 엄청 관심이 있어서 그 분야에서 일하고 싶어하는데, 그건 괜찮아요. 하지만 더 중요한 건 그 일을 가장 잘하는 사람을 따라가는 거예요. 단순히 좋아서 따라가는 것으로는 부족해요. 최고의 프로덕트 씽커(product thinker)나 최고의 엔지니어, 최고의 영업 담당자 같은 사람을 따라가야 그 분야에서 최고가 되는 법을 배우게 돼요.
text_zh: 我一直相信的是，你要跟对人。从人身上能学到最多东西。我不会专门去找什么行业领域。有些人确实对某个领域特别感兴趣，比如说特别想做气候相关的，想在那个领域深耕，这也没问题。但关键是你要跟那些在各自领域做得最牛的人。光是跟你喜欢的人混是不够的，你得跟那些要么是最顶尖的产品思维高手，要么是最牛的工程师，要么是最厉害的销售。这样你才能真正学会怎么在那个领域做到最好。
text_es: Lo que creo, y siempre he creído, es que hay que seguir a las personas. De la gente es de quien más aprendes. Yo no busco sectores específicos. Hay gente que tiene su sector, como "me interesa muchísimo el clima" o lo que sea, y realmente quieren trabajar en esa área, y está perfecto, entonces tal vez dentro de esa área. Pero tú sigues a las personas que son las mejores en lo que hacen. No basta con seguir a alguien que te cae bien. Quieres seguir a alguien que sea el mejor pensador de producto o el mejor ingeniero o el mejor vendedor. Así vas a aprender la habilidad de cómo ser el mejor en eso.
context: Continuing the discussion about career planning, Tamar explains her philosophy for career progression without formal plans. Instead of focusing on specific industries or domains, she advocates following exceptional people - those who are genuinely the best at their craft, whether in product thinking, engineering, or sales. She emphasizes that personal likability isn't enough; you need to work with people who excel at their skills so you can learn how to become exceptional yourself.
vocabulary_highlights: follow people, not good enough

speaker: Tamar Yehoshua
speaker_expertise: Product Design, AI/ML Products, Team Building
text: I got a piece of advice from a friend that I thought was amazing advice as a leader. She said to me, 'Take a job where if you hire people, it's going to make their careers.' I was like, 'Whoa.' Because I was getting offers for some turnaround jobs. And if you think you can turn around, great. But if you're going to hire the best people, you want to make sure that it's going to be a good place for them and that they're going to learn and they're going to grow.
text_ko: 친구한테서 들은 조언이 하나 있는데, 리더로서 정말 놀랍다고 생각했어요. 친구가 "사람을 뽑을 때 그들의 경력을 만들어줄 수 있는 직장을 선택해라"라고 하더라고요. 저는 '와' 했어요. 그때 저도 몇 군데 턴어라운드(turnaround) 자리 제안을 받고 있었거든요. 회사를 되살릴 수 있다고 생각한다면 그건 좋은 일이죠. 하지만 최고의 사람들을 뽑을 거라면, 그곳이 그들에게 좋은 자리인지, 배우고 성장할 수 있는지 확실히 확인해야 해요.
text_zh: 有个朋友给了我一个建议，我觉得对做领导来说特别棒。她跟我说："找工作的时候，要找那种你招进来的人能在那儿成就事业的地方。"我当时就想，哇，太对了。因为当时我手上有几个转型重组(turnaround)的工作机会，你觉得自己能搞定转型，那当然很好。但问题是，如果你要招最优秀的人才，你得确保这个地方对他们来说是个好平台，他们在这儿能学到东西，能成长起来。
text_es: Una amiga me dio un consejo que me pareció buenísimo como líder. Me dijo: "Acepta un trabajo donde, si contratas gente, les vayas a impulsar la carrera". Me quedé como "¡Órale!" Porque estaba recibiendo ofertas para algunos trabajos de reestructuración (turnaround). Y si crees que puedes darle la vuelta a la situación, perfecto. Pero si vas a contratar a los mejores, tienes que asegurarte de que va a ser un buen lugar para ellos, que van a aprender y van a crecer.
context: Lenny discusses the concept of companies having gravitational pull for talent. Tamar shares advice she received from a friend about leadership job selection. When she was considering various leadership roles, including some turnaround situations, her friend suggested she only take positions where hiring people would advance their careers. This advice made her realize she should evaluate opportunities not just for her own benefit, but for whether she could genuinely help the people she'd recruit to learn and grow.
vocabulary_highlights: make their careers, turnaround jobs

speaker: Tanguy Crusson
speaker_expertise: Product Strategy, Company Building, Product Management
text: The company has a tendency to over-invest. Startups have the benefit of starving, and so you need to create scarcity. What we try to do is remind everyone things are going to fail, let's not drag the rest of the company into it.
text_ko: 회사에는 과도하게 투자(over-invest)하는 경향이 있어요. 스타트업(startup)은 '배고픔'(starving)이 주는 이점이 있어서 의도적으로 희소성(scarcity)을 만들어야 해요. 우리는 모두에게 일이 실패할 수 있다는 걸 상기시키고, 실패하면 회사 전체를 끌어들이지 않도록 해요.
text_zh: 我们公司有个毛病，就是容易投入过度。初创公司其实挺好的，因为资源紧张，所以你得人为制造一种紧迫感。我们现在就是要时刻提醒大家，有些项目肯定会失败，别让整个公司都跟着陪葬。
text_es: La empresa tiende a invertir de más. Las startups tienen la ventaja de que están con el agua al cuello, así que necesitas crear esa escasez. Lo que tratamos de hacer es recordarle a todo el mundo que las cosas van a fallar, no arrastremos al resto de la empresa con nosotros.
context: Lenny asks why it's so hard to start new products within large companies. Tanguy explains one of the key challenges: large companies have resources but lack the natural constraints that help startups focus. He advocates for artificially creating scarcity and setting expectations that new bets will likely fail to prevent the broader organization from over-investing too early.
vocabulary_highlights: over-invest, benefit of starving, create scarcity, drag the rest of the company into it

speaker: Tanguy Crusson
speaker_expertise: Product Strategy, Company Building, Product Management
text: Be very clear about what we're testing, doing that with data, doing that with personal customer stories, give people a sense of velocity and speed. No one wants to fuck with a high-speed train.
text_ko: 우리가 무엇을 테스트하는지 아주 분명히 하세요. 그걸 데이터로 보여주고, 실제 고객의 개인적인 이야기로 뒷받침하세요. 사람들에게 속도(velocity)를 체감하게 해 주세요. 아무도 고속열차를 건드리고 싶어 하지 않아요.
text_zh: 要明确我们在测什么，用数据说话，用客户的真实故事说话，让大家感受到我们的速度和冲劲。没人愿意去撞高铁，对吧？
text_es: Sé muy claro sobre lo que estamos probando, hazlo con datos, hazlo with historias reales de clientes, dale a la gente una sensación de velocidad y momentum. Nadie se va a meter con un tren de alta velocidad.
context: Lenny discusses the challenge companies face when leadership wants to kill new products after six months of slow progress. Tanguy shares his strategy for protecting new initiatives by maintaining clear communication about what's being tested, backing it up with both data and compelling customer stories, and demonstrating consistent momentum to discourage interference from other parts of the organization.
vocabulary_highlights: sense of velocity, fuck with, high-speed train
