speaker: Tanguy Crusson
speaker_expertise: Product Strategy, Company Building, Product Management
text: My track record at Atlassian has been 50/50 at best. Jira Project Discovery is actually my first, what I would call big success here. That one worked, but it was hard and all the ones that I worked on before were really hard to, and that's the kind of stuff that really bothered me for a super long time.
text_ko: 아틀라시안(Atlassian)에서의 성과는 잘해봐야 반반이었어요. 사실 여기서 제가 ‘큰 성공’이라고 부를 만한 건 지라 프로젝트 디스커버리(Jira Project Discovery)가 처음이에요. 그건 잘 됐지만 정말 힘들었고, 그전까지 제가 맡았던 것들은 전부 성공시키기 어려웠어요. 그런 점들이 한동안 저를 많이 괴롭혔어요.
text_zh: 我在Atlassian的成功率最多也就五五开吧。Jira Project Discovery其实是我在这儿的第一个大成功项目。这个项目算是成了，但做起来真的很费劲，之前搞的那些项目也都特别难搞，这种事情真的让我郁闷了好长时间。
text_es: Mi historial en Atlassian ha sido como del 50/50, siendo generoso. Jira Project Discovery es en realidad mi primer gran éxito aquí, lo que yo consideraría un éxito grande de verdad. Ese proyecto sí funcionó, pero fue durísimo, y todos los anteriores en los que trabajé también fueron súper difíciles, y ese tipo de cosas me tenían muy frustrado durante muchísimo tiempo.
context: Tanguy shares his honest assessment of building zero-to-one products at Atlassian over 10 years. He's worked on products like HipChat, Stride, and Statuspage with mixed results. Jira Product Discovery represents his first major success, but he emphasizes that even successful outcomes in large companies involve significant struggles and setbacks along the way.
vocabulary_highlights: 50/50 at best, bothered me for a super long time

speaker: Tanguy Crusson
speaker_expertise: Product Strategy, Company Building, Product Management
text: We made the bet that we can apply this playbook to this market, which is basically we can, from people to use Jira, introduce HipChat, and then people will go into HipChat first in tech teams, and then it will expand into business teams, and it'll go world to world basically from that. The thing is we didn't, in my opinion, do enough to validate that assumption early enough.
text_ko: 우리는 이 플레이북(playbook)을 이 시장에 적용할 수 있다고 베팅했어요. 요컨대 사람들이 지라(Jira)를 쓰게 하고 힙챗(HipChat)을 도입하면, 기술팀에서 먼저 힙챗을 쓰기 시작하고 그게 비즈니스팀으로 확장되면서 결국 전 세계로 퍼질 거라고 본 거죠. 근데 제 생각엔 그 가정을 초기에 충분히 검증하지 못했어요.
text_zh: 我们当时赌的是能把这套打法用到这个市场上，基本上就是说，从用Jira的用户开始，推HipChat，然后大家会先在技术团队里用HipChat，接着扩展到业务团队，基本上就这样一步步铺开。问题是，我觉得我们没有早一点去充分验证这个假设。
text_es: Apostamos a que podíamos aplicar esta estrategia a este mercado, básicamente que podíamos lograr que la gente que ya usa Jira adoptara HipChat, y entonces la gente empezaría a usar HipChat primero en los equipos de tecnología, luego se expandiría a los equipos de negocio, y así se iría extendiendo mundo por mundo. El tema es que no hicimos lo suficiente, en mi opinión, para validar esa suposición lo suficientemente temprano.
context: Tanguy explains Atlassian's failed strategy with HipChat, their enterprise communication product that competed with Slack. Atlassian assumed their successful bottom-up adoption model from developer tools would work for business communication tools. However, they didn't adequately test whether their existing customer base in tech teams would actually drive adoption in business teams, leading to strategic missteps.
vocabulary_highlights: apply this playbook, world to world, validate that assumption

speaker: Tanguy Crusson
speaker_expertise: Product Strategy, Company Building, Product Management
text: At some point, the Slack was really gaining round and gaining round and capturing more of the mindshare. And everyone on Twitter was always loving them. Even when they had outrages, they were getting congratulated. I was like, 'This is working mad.' But the love was so strong, and the way we tended to revert back is to our functional side of the brain going, okay, we just need this one more feature.
text_ko: 어느 순간 슬랙은 계속 성장하면서 사람들 머릿속 점유율(mindshare)을 점점 더 차지했어요. 트위터에서는 항상 사람들이 그들을 좋아했죠. 논란이 있어도 오히려 축하를 받는 경우가 많았어요. 저도 ‘이거 진짜 잘 되고 있네’라고 생각했어요. 그런데 그 사랑이 워낙 강해서, 우리는 본능적으로 기능적인 쪽으로 되돌아가 ‘좋아, 우리한테 딱 하나 기능만 더 있으면 돼’라고 생각하게 되더라고요.
text_zh: 有段时间，Slack真的是越来越火，越来越火，占据了更多的心智份额(mindshare)。Twitter上所有人都特别喜欢他们。就算他们出了故障，大家还在那儿夸他们。我当时就想，'这也太厉害了吧。'但是用户的喜爱太强烈了，我们的习惯性反应就是回到功能思维上，觉得我们就是缺这么一个功能。
text_es: En un momento dado, Slack estaba ganando terreno y cada vez más terreno, y se estaba apoderando de la atención del mercado (mindshare). Y toda la gente en Twitter los adoraba. Hasta cuando tenían problemas técnicos, los felicitaban. Yo pensaba, 'Esto está funcionando de maravilla.' Pero el cariño era tan fuerte, y nuestra tendencia era volver a la parte funcional del cerebro y decir, bueno, solo necesitamos una función más.
context: Tanguy describes the competitive dynamics between HipChat and Slack, warning against 'competitive myopia.' He explains how Slack gained significant mindshare and customer love, even during outages. This led Atlassian to fall into a trap of reactive feature development, constantly trying to match Slack's features rather than focusing on serving their own customers' unique needs.
vocabulary_highlights: gaining round, capturing more of the mindshare, outrages, revert back, functional side of the brain

speaker: Tanguy Crusson
speaker_expertise: Product Strategy, Company Building, Product Management
text: Everyone was excited, thought it made sense, lots of encouragement. I pitched it to every level of the organization from business leaders, to the CTO that we had at the time, to the CEOs. No one said no, no one said yes. For months.
text_ko: 다들 기대했고, 말이 된다고 생각했으며, 응원도 많이 받았어요. 비즈니스 리더들(business leaders)부터 당시 우리 최고기술책임자(CTO), CEO들(CEOs)에 이르기까지 조직의 모든 레벨에 제안했어요. 그런데 아무도 반대하지도, 찬성하지도 않았어요. 몇 달 동안요.
text_zh: 大家都很兴奋，觉得这想法挺靠谱的，给了我不少鼓励。我把这个方案推给了公司各个层级的人——业务负责人、当时的CTO、还有CEO们。结果呢，没人说不行，也没人拍板说行。就这么拖了好几个月。
text_es: Todo el mundo estaba emocionado, pensaban que tenía sentido, me daban mucho apoyo. Se lo presenté a todos los niveles de la organización, desde los líderes de negocio hasta el CTO que teníamos en ese momento, hasta los CEOs. Nadie dijo que no, nadie dijo que sí. Durante meses.
context: Tanguy describes his frustrating experience trying to get approval for an IT operations business case at Atlassian before their internal incubator program existed. Despite positive feedback from all levels of leadership including CTOs and CEOs, the project remained in limbo for months without clear approval or rejection, highlighting the challenge of getting new initiatives prioritized in large organizations.
vocabulary_highlights: pitched it to every level, no one said no, no one said yes

speaker: Tanguy Crusson
speaker_expertise: Product Strategy, Company Building, Product Management
text: What we needed is to create this area where we could experiment that's away from Jira while being inside Jira. That part was a bit tough. It's possible to do. In fact, I came across an article from Ben Weiss. No, sorry, Noah Weiss, it's from many years ago now. Where he was basically talking about innovating in a successful material product and talked about three stages of incubate, iterate, integrate.
text_ko: 우리가 필요했던 건 Jira에서 벗어나면서도 Jira 안에서 실험할 수 있는 공간을 만드는 거였어요. 그 부분이 좀 어려웠죠. 하지만 가능해요. 사실, 몇 년 전에 Noah Weiss의 글을 봤는데, 그가 성공적인 물질 제품에서 혁신하는 방법에 대해 이야기하면서 세 가지 단계인 인큐베이트(incubate), 이터레이트(iterate), 인티그레이트(integrate)에 대해 설명했어요.
text_zh: 我们当时需要的是在Jira里面搞一个可以做实验的地方，但又要跟现有的功能分开。这块确实挺难搞的。不过是可以做到的。其实我之前看到过Ben Weiss的一篇文章，不对，是Noah Weiss，那是好多年前的事了。他基本上就是在讲怎么在一个已经很成功的产品里做创新，提到了三个阶段：孵化、迭代、整合。
text_es: Lo que necesitábamos era crear esta área donde pudiéramos experimentar que estuviera fuera de Jira pero a la vez dentro de Jira. Esa parte fue un poco complicada. Sí se puede hacer. De hecho, me topé con un artículo de Ben Weiss. No, perdón, Noah Weiss, es de hace muchos años ya. Donde básicamente hablaba de cómo innovar en un producto material exitoso y mencionaba tres etapas: incubar, iterar, integrar.
context: Tanguy explains how they approached building Jira Product Discovery for product managers without disrupting Jira's existing user base of 120,000 customers. He references Noah Weiss's framework of 'incubate, iterate, integrate' - starting with isolated experiments, refining them separately, then integrating successful features back into the main product. This approach allowed them to reimagine Jira's experience for a specific audience without breaking existing workflows.
vocabulary_highlights: away from Jira while being inside Jira, incubate, iterate, integrate

speaker: Greg Isenberg
text: The gap between what people think business is and what actually happens is what Scott Belsky calls the messy middle. Think of The Social Network, the movie. Mark Zuckerberg starts Facebook and then all of a sudden it's massive. It's this romantic idea that people have about startups and entrepreneurship. In reality, the messy middle, the time in between starting and the outcome is 99% of the process of business and startups and entrepreneurship.
text_ko: 사람들이 비즈니스가 어떤 건지 생각하는 것과 실제로 벌어지는 일 사이의 격차를 스콧 벨스키는 '혼란스러운 중간 단계(messy middle)'라고 부르죠. 영화 '소셜 네트워크'를 떠올려 보세요. 마크 저커버그가 페이스북을 만들고 갑자기 엄청나게 커지는 장면이요. 사람들이 스타트업이나 창업에 대해 갖는 그런 낭만적인 환상이에요. 현실은 그게 아니고, 시작과 결과 사이에 있는 그 어중간한 시간, 즉 혼란스러운 중간 단계(messy middle)가 비즈니스나 스타트업, 창업 과정의 99%를 차지해요.
text_zh: 大家以为做生意是怎么回事，跟实际情况之间的差距，Scott Belsky管这叫"混乱中期(messy middle)"。你想想《社交网络》那部电影，马克·扎克伯格创立Facebook，然后突然间就做大了。大家对创业都有这种浪漫化的想法。但现实是什么呢？这个混乱中期(messy middle)，也就是从开始到最终结果之间的那段时间，才是做生意、搞创业99%的真实过程。
text_es: La brecha entre lo que la gente cree que es hacer negocios y lo que realmente pasa es lo que Scott Belsky llama el medio desordenado (messy middle). Piensen en la película The Social Network. Mark Zuckerberg lanza Facebook y de repente ya es masivo. Es esa idea romántica que tiene la gente sobre las startups y el emprendimiento. En la realidad, ese medio desordenado, el tiempo que pasa entre empezar y ver los resultados, es el 99% de todo el proceso de los negocios, las startups y el emprendimiento.
context: Greg is explaining one of the biggest misconceptions people have about entrepreneurship. He references Scott Belsky's concept of 'the messy middle' - the long, difficult period between starting a business and achieving success. Greg contrasts the romanticized portrayal of instant success (like in The Social Network movie) with the reality that 99% of entrepreneurship is actually grinding through this challenging middle phase.
vocabulary_highlights: the messy middle, romantic idea, rise up, zig and zag

speaker: Sahil Bloom
text: So in my mind, the biggest gap between what people think business is versus what it really is, is that aspect of just crawling through the river of shit that exists between where you start and where you finish. It's like The Shawshank Redemption. You got to just go through that period.
text_ko: 제 생각엔 사람들이 비즈니스가 어떤 건지 착각하는 가장 큰 차이는, 시작과 끝 사이에 있는 그 지독하고 지저분한 구간을 그저 기어가듯 통과해야 한다는 점이에요. 진짜 '쇼생크 탈출' 같아요. 그냥 그 시기를 버텨야 해요.
text_zh: 我觉得吧，大家对做生意的理解和现实最大的差距就是，从起点到终点这中间，你得咬牙熬过那段特别煎熬的日子。就像《肖申克的救赎》里一样，那段苦日子你必须得撑过去。
text_es: Entonces, para mí, la diferencia más grande entre lo que la gente piensa que es hacer negocios versus la realidad, es esa parte de tener que arrastrarte por toda la mierda que hay entre donde empiezas y donde terminas. Es como en Cadena Perpetua. Tienes que pasar por ese periodo, no hay de otra.
context: Sahil is responding to the same question about misconceptions in business. He uses a vivid metaphor from The Shawshank Redemption movie to describe the difficult journey entrepreneurs face. He's explaining that the unglamorous, painful middle period of building a business is what most people don't understand or talk about, even though it's the most important part of the entrepreneurial journey.
vocabulary_highlights: crawling through the river of shit, got to just go through that period

speaker: Greg Isenberg
text: And that's when I realized I could do anything. The moment that changed my mind about business and opportunity was the first time I ever went to Silicon Valley. I was reading up about all these entrepreneurs, all these investors on places like TechCrunch. And I landed and I expected them to be incredibly great, so much different from you and I. And I started having conversations with them and I realized they weren't smarter than us.
text_ko: 그때야 제가 뭐든 할 수 있겠다는 걸 깨달았어요. 사업과 기회에 대한 제 생각을 바꿔놓은 순간은 제가 처음 실리콘밸리(Silicon Valley)에 갔던 때예요. 테크크런치(TechCrunch) 같은 데서 온갖 창업가들과 투자자들에 대한 글을 읽어왔고요. 막 도착했을 땐 그 사람들이 엄청 대단하고 우리랑은 완전히 다를 거라고 기대했어요. 그런데 얘기해보니 그들이 우리보다 똑똑한 게 아니라는 걸 알게 됐어요.
text_zh: 就是在那一刻，我意识到自己什么都能做到。真正改变我对商业和机会看法的那个时刻，是我第一次去硅谷(Silicon Valley)的时候。我之前一直在TechCrunch这些网站上看那些创业者和投资人的报道。落地之后，我本来以为他们会特别厉害，跟咱们完全不是一个级别的。结果跟他们聊了之后我发现，他们其实也没比咱们聪明到哪儿去。
text_es: Y ahí fue cuando me di cuenta de que podía hacer cualquier cosa. El momento que me cambió la mentalidad sobre los negocios y las oportunidades fue la primera vez que fui a Silicon Valley. Estaba leyendo sobre todos estos emprendedores, todos estos inversionistas en sitios como TechCrunch. Y cuando llegué esperaba que fueran increíblemente geniales, súper diferentes a ti y a mí. Y empecé a platicar con ellos y me di cuenta de que no eran más inteligentes que nosotros.
context: Greg is sharing a pivotal moment in his entrepreneurial journey. He describes his first visit to Silicon Valley, where he had built up expectations about tech entrepreneurs and investors based on media coverage. However, when he actually met and spoke with these people in person, he realized they weren't inherently more intelligent than anyone else - they just had better access to resources and networks.
vocabulary_highlights: reading up about, incredibly great

speaker: Sahil Bloom
text: What frustrates me most about the current state of podcasts is just that it's one sided. It all ends as soon as you finish the conversation during the interview. It's an interview, you talk to someone, you ask them questions and then it ends and that's it. That's all you get from them.
text_ko: 지금 팟캐스트(podcast)에서 가장 답답한 건 일방적이라는 점이에요. 인터뷰(interview)가 끝나면 대화도 그대로 끝나버려요. 누군가와 얘기하고 질문을 던지면 그게 끝이고, 거기서 더 이어지지도 않아요. 그 사람에게서 얻는 건 그게 전부예요.
text_zh: 播客(podcast)现在最让我头疼的就是太单向了。采访一结束，对话就彻底断了。就是采访嘛，你跟人聊天，问几个问题，然后就没了，就这些，你再也得不到什么了。
text_es: Lo que más me frustra del estado actual de los podcasts es que son muy unidireccionales. Todo se acaba en cuanto terminas la conversación durante la entrevista. Es una entrevista, hablas con alguien, les haces preguntas y luego se acaba y ya está. Eso es todo lo que sacas de ellos.
context: Sahil is critiquing the traditional podcast format and explaining his motivation for creating something different. He's frustrated that most podcasts are purely transactional - you listen to an interview, but there's no opportunity for follow-up, deeper engagement, or building relationships with the guests or insights shared. This criticism sets up their vision for a more interactive, community-driven approach to podcasting.
vocabulary_highlights: one sided, that's all you get from them

speaker: Greg Isenberg
text: We're in this for the long game. And what excites me about... I mean, the reason why I got into community was because I love seeing people progress, advance, do big things. And I know that being a part of The Room Where it Happens, good things will happen to you.
text_ko: 저희는 이걸 장기전(long game)으로 보고 있어요. 사실 제가 설레는 이유는... 제가 커뮤니티(community)에 뛰어든 건 사람들이 성장하고 더 발전해서 큰일을 해내는 모습을 보는 걸 정말 좋아하기 때문이에요. 그리고 'The Room Where it Happens'에 함께하면 여러분에게 좋은 일들이 생길 거라고 믿어요.
text_zh: 我们做的是长远的事情。让我特别兴奋的是...我的意思是，我之所以投身社群这个领域，就是因为我特别喜欢看到大家不断进步，不断突破，做出一番事业来。我很清楚，只要你加入了The Room Where it Happens这个圈子，好事肯定会找上门的。
text_es: Nosotros estamos aquí para el largo plazo. Y lo que me emociona de esto... o sea, la razón por la que me metí en el tema de comunidad fue porque me encanta ver a la gente progresar, avanzar, hacer cosas grandes. Y sé que siendo parte de The Room Where it Happens, te van a pasar cosas buenas.
context: Greg is explaining his long-term vision and personal motivation for creating The Room Where it Happens community. He's expressing his commitment to building something sustainable over time, rather than seeking quick results. Greg shares that his passion for community building stems from watching people grow and achieve success, and he believes their community will be a catalyst for members' future accomplishments.
vocabulary_highlights: in this for the long game, do big things

speaker: Teresa Torres
text: So first of all, it's just a really simple visual. It's funny how simple it looks, because using it in practice is really complex. I definitely have a new appreciation for that, trying to teach it over and over again and seeing where people struggle.
text_ko: 먼저, 보기에는 정말 단순한 비주얼이에요. 이렇게 단순해 보이는 게 신기한데, 실제로 현장에서 써보면 훨씬 복잡해요. 계속 반복해서 가르치다 보니 사람들이 어디서 어려워하는지 보이더라고요, 그래서 그 복잡함을 새삼 더 인정하게 됐어요.
text_zh: 首先吧，这个图表看起来特别简单。挺有意思的是，看着简单，但真正用起来其实挺复杂的。我现在是真的体会到了这一点，因为我反复教了好多次，也看到大家都在哪些地方容易卡住。
text_es: Bueno, antes que nada, es una imagen súper sencilla. Es curioso lo simple que se ve, porque cuando lo pones en práctica es realmente complejo. Definitivamente ahora lo valoro más, después de intentar enseñarlo una y otra vez y ver dónde se traba la gente.
context: Lenny asks Teresa to explain the opportunity solution tree framework and what problem it solves for product teams. Teresa begins by describing the framework as a visual tree structure that starts with an outcome and branches into opportunities and solutions. She emphasizes that while the framework appears deceptively simple, implementing it effectively requires significant skill and deep thinking.
vocabulary_highlights: new appreciation for, over and over again

speaker: Teresa Torres
text: But it's the opposite of how our brains are wired. And so, teaching people to be comfortable with that discomfort of staying there is hard. I mean I see blog posts written about how they're using the opportunity solution tree, and I cry a little bit because their opportunity space is all solutions.
text_ko: 근데 그건 우리 뇌가 작동하는 방식과 정반대예요. 그래서 사람들에게 그 불편함을 안고 거기에 머무르는 데 익숙해지라고 가르치는 건 어렵습니다. 제 말은, 기회-솔루션 트리(opportunity solution tree)를 사용한다고 올린 블로그 포스트들을 보면 좀 울컥해요. 그들이 정의한 기회 영역(opportunity space)은 전부 솔루션뿐이거든요.
text_zh: 但这跟我们大脑的天然反应是反着来的。所以要教会大家适应这种不舒服、让他们能待在这个状态里，真的挺难的。我经常看到一些博客文章写他们怎么用机会解决方案树(opportunity solution tree)，看完我都想哭，因为他们的机会空间(opportunity space)里全是解决方案。
text_es: Pero es justo lo contrario a como funciona nuestro cerebro. Y entonces, enseñarle a la gente a sentirse cómoda con esa incomodidad de quedarse ahí es súper difícil. O sea, veo posts de blog sobre cómo están usando el árbol de oportunidades y soluciones (opportunity solution tree), y me da como una pena tremenda porque su espacio de oportunidades está lleno puras soluciones.
context: Teresa explains why the opportunity solution tree framework is challenging to implement correctly. She discusses how product teams struggle to distinguish between problems (opportunities) and solutions, with 98% of people incorrectly writing opportunities as solutions. The core difficulty is that humans naturally want to jump to solutions rather than spend time properly understanding and framing problems.
vocabulary_highlights: opposite of how our brains are wired, cry a little bit

speaker: Teresa Torres
text: The challenge with that is we know from human psychology and cognitive psychology that we're not very good at answering those questions out of context. Actually, that sounds weird. We're very good at answering them. Your brain will come up with a fast answer, but that answer doesn't necessarily reflect your behavior, and it misses context and nuance.
text_ko: 문제는 인간심리학(human psychology)과 인지심리학(cognitive psychology)에서 알다시피 그런 질문을 맥락 없이는 잘 답하지 못한다는 거예요. 사실 이렇게 말하면 이상하게 들리죠. 우리는 그런 질문에는 오히려 아주 빠르게 답을 내놓아요. 그런데 그 빠른 답이 꼭 실제 행동을 반영하는 건 아니고, 맥락과 뉘앙스(nuance)를 놓쳐요.
text_zh: 这里的问题是，从人类心理学和认知心理学的角度来看，我们其实不太擅长脱离具体情境来回答这类问题。其实这么说有点奇怪，我们确实很会回答——你的大脑会很快给出一个答案，但这个答案不一定能反映你真正的行为，而且会忽略掉具体的情境和细节。
text_es: El problema con eso es que sabemos por la psicología humana y cognitiva que no somos muy buenos respondiendo esas preguntas sin contexto. Bueno, en realidad suena raro decirlo así. Sí somos muy buenos respondiéndolas. Tu cerebro te da una respuesta rápida, pero esa respuesta no necesariamente refleja tu comportamiento real, y se pierde el contexto y los matices.
context: Teresa explains why traditional interviewing approaches fail when trying to understand customer opportunities. She contrasts asking direct questions like 'What do you like to watch on Netflix?' with collecting specific stories about recent experiences. The key insight is that while people readily provide answers to direct questions, these responses often don't accurately reflect their actual behavior because they lack the context and nuance of real situations.
vocabulary_highlights: out of context, fast answer, reflect your behavior, context and nuance

speaker: Teresa Torres
text: So there's a lot of skill involved. I wish I could just say, 'Hey, Lenny. It's super easy. Everybody should do it. I think it's really powerful, and I've seen it be a game-changer for teams. It's hard.
text_ko: 그래서 많은 기술이 필요해요. 그냥 "레니, 정말 쉬워요. 누구나 해야 해요. 저는 이게 정말 강력하다고 생각하고 팀들에게는 판도를 바꿔놓는(game-changer) 경우도 봤어요."라고 말할 수 있으면 좋겠어요. 그런데 어려워요.
text_zh: 这里面有很多技巧。我真希望能直接跟你说，"嘿，Lenny，这超简单的，人人都能做。"但实际上这真的很有用，我见过它彻底改变团队的表现。只是确实不容易。
text_es: Entonces sí requiere mucha habilidad. Ojalá pudiera simplemente decir, 'Oye, Lenny. Es súper fácil. Todo el mundo debería hacerlo.' Creo que es realmente poderoso, y he visto que puede cambiar completamente la dinámica de los equipos (game-changer). Pero es difícil.
context: Teresa responds to Lenny's question about how product managers can create their own opportunity solution trees. She explains that the process requires multiple complex skills: interviewing well to collect customer stories, being able to identify opportunities versus solutions, framing opportunities specifically, and structuring the opportunity space using experience maps. Despite the difficulty, she emphasizes that teams willing to invest in developing these skills see transformational results.
vocabulary_highlights: game-changer, skill involved

speaker: Teresa Torres
text: I tell my teams when I teach it in class, I say, 'Look, we're going to focus on structuring an opportunity space, and I'm probably going to make you think harder than you've ever had to think in your job,' because we don't think that much at work. We go from meeting to meeting, we stay surface level a lot, and here I am coming in with this really hard critical thinking exercise.
text_ko: 수업에서 이걸 가르칠 때 팀원들에게 이렇게 말해요. "자, 우리는 기회 영역(opportunity space)을 구조화하는 데 집중할 거예요. 그리고 아마 여러분이 지금까지 직장에서 해본 것보다 훨씬 더 깊게 생각하게 만들 것 같아요." 왜냐하면 직장에서는 사실 그렇게 많이 생각하지 않거든요. 회의에서 회의로 옮겨 다니고 많은 경우 표면적인 수준에만 머무르죠. 그런데 제가 들어와서 정말 어려운 비판적 사고 연습(critical thinking exercise)을 시키는 거예요.
text_zh: 我跟团队上课的时候就跟他们说："咱们要重点学习如何构建机会空间(opportunity space)，我可能会让你们动脑子动得比平时工作还累，"因为咱们平时工作其实不怎么深度思考。天天开会开会的，很多时候都是浮在表面，结果我来了就给大家来了个特别烧脑的批判性思维训练。
text_es: Les digo a mis equipos cuando lo enseño en clase: "Miren, nos vamos a enfocar en estructurar un espacio de oportunidades, y probablemente los voy a hacer pensar más fuerte de lo que han tenido que pensar en su trabajo", porque la verdad es que no pensamos tanto en el trabajo. Vamos de junta en junta, nos quedamos muy en la superficie la mayoría del tiempo, y aquí llego yo con este ejercicio súper pesado de pensamiento crítico.
context: Teresa continues explaining the difficulty of implementing the opportunity solution tree framework effectively. She describes how the deep thinking required for structuring opportunity spaces is unlike typical work activities. Most professionals spend their days in meetings and surface-level discussions, but this framework demands intensive critical thinking and analysis to properly understand customer needs and frame problems correctly.
vocabulary_highlights: surface level, critical thinking exercise

speaker: Teresa Torres
text: So we overthink it. We think we have to go through these proper channels and we have to get permission from sales. A lot of us, especially if we work on a consumer product, just go find somebody that's like your user.
text_ko: 우리는 그걸 너무 복잡하게 생각해요. 정해진 절차를 밟아야 하고 영업(sales) 쪽의 허락을 받아야 한다고 생각하죠. 근데 많은 사람들, 특히 소비자용 제품(consumer product)을 다루는 사람들은 그냥 사용자(user)랑 비슷한 사람을 찾아가서 직접 얘기해봐요.
text_zh: 所以我们就想多了。我们觉得必须走正规渠道，必须得到销售那边的批准。其实我们很多人，特别是做消费产品的，直接去找个跟你们用户差不多的人就行了。
text_es: Entonces le damos demasiadas vueltas. Pensamos que tenemos que seguir todos los canales oficiales y que necesitamos el visto bueno del equipo de ventas. Muchos de nosotros, sobre todo si trabajamos en un producto de consumo, simplemente vamos y buscamos a alguien que sea como nuestro usuario.
context: Lenny asks how individual contributors can use discovery frameworks even in feature factory environments. Teresa advises focusing on changing individual work habits rather than trying to force organizational change. She addresses the common excuse that people aren't 'allowed' to talk to customers, suggesting they can start by talking to people in their personal networks who resemble their users, rather than getting caught up in formal approval processes.
vocabulary_highlights: overthink it, proper channels

speaker: Teresa Torres
text: That's not our business environment. Our businesses are expecting us to deliver continuous value, so we need to look at how do we match that cadence. What I think is really nice about continuous discovery, you can do it in as little as an interview a week, on the interviewing side, on the discovering opportunity side.
text_ko: 그건 우리 사업 환경이 아니에요. 우리 비즈니스는 지속적인 가치(continuous value)를 제공하길 기대하니까, 그 페이스(cadence)에 어떻게 맞출지 봐야 해요. 제가 보기엔 지속적 탐색(continuous discovery)의 좋은 점은, 인터뷰 측면에서는 일주일에 인터뷰 한 건만 해도 되고, 기회 발굴(discovering opportunity) 측면에서도 그렇게 적은 노력으로도 할 수 있다는 거예요.
text_zh: 我们的商业环境不是这样的。我们的业务方期望我们能持续创造价值，所以我们得看看怎么跟上这个节奏。我觉得持续发现(continuous discovery)特别好的一点就是，你可以做得很轻量，比如在访谈这块，在发现机会这块，一周做一次访谈就够了。
text_es: Ese no es nuestro entorno de negocio. Nuestras empresas esperan que les entreguemos valor continuo, así que tenemos que ver cómo nos adaptamos a ese ritmo. Lo que me parece realmente bueno del descubrimiento continuo (continuous discovery) es que puedes hacerlo con tan solo una entrevista a la semana, por el lado de las entrevistas, por el lado de descubrir oportunidades.
context: Teresa responds to a common objection from leaders who say there's no time for discovery work. She explains that continuous discovery is designed to match the fast-paced business environment, unlike traditional project-based research methods that require stopping work to conduct lengthy studies. The key insight is that discovery can be done sustainably with just one customer interview per week, making it feasible even in time-constrained environments.
vocabulary_highlights: match that cadence, as little as

speaker: Tim Holley
text: The other thing to me is bringing an outside in perspective, really benchmarking against your competitors and your competitive set. Don't get me wrong, I think Etsy is a unique marketplace. Our sellers are independent sellers. They sell unique items. The reality though is that our buyers are shopping all over the internet.
text_ko: 또 한 가지 중요한 건 외부 시각(outside-in perspective)을 들여와서 경쟁사들과 경쟁군(competitive set)을 진짜로 벤치마킹(benchmarking)하는 거예요. 오해하지 마세요, 저는 Etsy가 정말 독특한 마켓플레이스(marketplace)라고 생각해요. 우리 판매자들은 독립적이고 독특한 상품을 팔아요. 하지만 현실은 구매자들이 인터넷 곳곳에서 쇼핑을 하고 있다는 거예요.
text_zh: 另外一点我觉得很重要的是，要有外部视角，真正去对标你的竞争对手和整个竞争格局。别误会我的意思，我觉得Etsy确实是个很独特的市场平台。我们的卖家都是独立卖家，卖的都是独一无二的商品。但现实情况是，我们的买家在整个互联网上到处购物。
text_es: Lo otro que me parece clave es traer esa perspectiva de afuera hacia adentro, realmente hacer un benchmarking contra tus competidores y tu conjunto competitivo. No me malinterpretes, creo que Etsy es un marketplace único. Nuestros vendedores son vendedores independientes. Venden artículos únicos. Pero la realidad es que nuestros compradores andan comprando por todo el internet.
context: Lenny asks Tim what Josh Silverman did well to help Etsy transition from a consensus-driven culture to a more business-focused approach in 2017. Tim explains that one key change was adopting an outside-in perspective by benchmarking against competitors. While Etsy is unique as a marketplace for independent sellers offering unique items, Tim emphasizes that buyers still shop across many different platforms and retailers, so Etsy needs to understand the broader competitive landscape to make better strategic decisions.
vocabulary_highlights: outside in perspective, benchmarking against, competitive set

speaker: Tim Holley
text: And having that be part of the day-to-day conversation, it seems like such a small thing, but it adds up to having clarity on goal, the KPI point, and then clarity on why, the narrative point. If you can marry those two things, I think that's an incredibly powerful combination.
text_ko: 그게 일상 대화의 일부가 되면 사소해 보일 수 있지만, 목표와 KPI(핵심성과지표)에 대한 명확성 그리고 왜 하는지에 대한 내러티브(narrative)가 쌓여요. 이 둘을 잘 결합시키면 정말 강력한 조합이 된다고 생각해요.
text_zh: 把这个融入到日常聊天中，看起来是个小事儿，但积累起来就能让目标更清晰——这是KPI这块，还有让大家明白为什么要这么做——这是讲故事这块。如果你能把这两点结合好，我觉得威力是相当大的。
text_es: Y que eso sea parte de las conversaciones del día a día, parece algo muy pequeño, pero al final se suma para tener claridad en el objetivo, el punto de los KPIs, y después claridad en el porqué, la parte narrativa. Si logras combinar esas dos cosas, creo que es una combinación tremendamente poderosa.
context: Lenny asks what Tim learned about making organizational change from watching Josh Silverman's leadership transition at Etsy. Tim explains that effective change requires both a clear KPI that teams can rally around and a consistent narrative explaining why the change matters. He notes that leaders need to repeat messages multiple times before people truly understand and internalize them, making day-to-day reinforcement critical for successful transformation.
vocabulary_highlights: marry those two things, incredibly powerful combination

speaker: Tim Holley
text: Our sellers are incredibly astute business people. And if you had been making wedding dresses, and you know how to sew, and you've got material, and you've got a bit of time, making a mask is quite a simple task. And so we just saw this huge surge of demand, and then supply rising to meet it.
text_ko: 우리 판매자들은 비즈니스 감각이 정말 뛰어나요. 예를 들어 웨딩드레스를 만들던 사람이 재봉을 할 줄 알고 재료도 있고 시간도 좀 있으면 마스크 만드는 건 꽤 쉬운 일이에요. 그래서 수요가 갑자기 크게 폭증했고 공급도 금방 그에 맞춰 늘어났어요.
text_zh: 我们的卖家都是特别精明的生意人。你想啊，如果你本来就在做婚纱，会缝纫，有面料，也有点时间，那做个口罩其实挺简单的。所以我们就看到需求量猛增，然后供应也跟着上来了。
text_es: Nuestros vendedores son gente de negocios súper hábil, ¿eh? Y fíjate, si ya venías haciendo vestidos de novia, y sabes coser, y tienes tela, y tienes un poco de tiempo, pues hacer un cubrebocas es pan comido. Entonces lo que vimos fue un pico de demanda impresionante, y después la oferta se fue ajustando para cubrirla.
context: Lenny asks Tim about Etsy's experience during COVID-19, particularly the massive growth in face mask sales. Tim explains how when the CDC mandated face masks in April 2020, Etsy experienced overnight Black Friday-level traffic and sales. He describes how Etsy's sellers quickly pivoted their skills - for example, wedding dress makers using their sewing abilities and materials to create face masks, demonstrating the marketplace's ability to rapidly adapt supply to meet urgent demand.
vocabulary_highlights: incredibly astute business people, huge surge of demand, supply rising to meet it

speaker: Tim Holley
text: And we did something that far as I know we've never done an Etsy's past, which is we put out a call to our sellers to say, 'Now's the time. Now's the time to make face masks if you can.' And so it felt like this is our time to shine, to really help sellers continue to make sales, to help buyers find this critical item that they were looking for.
text_ko: 그리고 제가 알기로는 Etsy 역사상 한 번도 해본 적이 없는 일을 했어요. 판매자들에게 “지금이 바로 때예요. 가능하면 지금 마스크를 만들어 주세요”라고 적극적으로 요청했어요. 그래서 이건 우리가 진짜 빛날 기회라고 느꼈어요 — 판매자들이 계속 매출을 이어가실 수 있게 돕고, 구매자들이 찾고 있던 꼭 필요한 물건을 찾을 수 있게 해주자는 마음이었어요.
text_zh: 据我所知，我们做了一件Etsy以前从来没做过的事情，就是我们主动号召我们的卖家说："机会来了，如果你们能做的话，现在就是做口罩的时候。" 感觉这就是我们大放异彩的时刻，真正帮助卖家继续做生意，帮买家找到他们急需的这个东西。
text_es: Y hicimos algo que, por lo que yo sé, nunca habíamos hecho antes en Etsy, que fue hacer un llamado a nuestros vendedores para decirles: 'Es el momento. Es el momento de hacer mascarillas si pueden.' Y entonces sentimos que esta era nuestra oportunidad de brillar, de realmente ayudar a los vendedores a seguir generando ventas, y ayudar a los compradores a encontrar este producto tan necesario que estaban buscando.
context: Tim continues describing Etsy's response during the early COVID-19 pandemic when face masks became mandatory. He explains that Etsy took the unprecedented step of actively encouraging their sellers to pivot and start making face masks. This was apparently the first time in Etsy's history that they had directly called on sellers to focus on a specific product category, showing how the company stepped up during a crisis to help both sellers maintain income and buyers access essential items.
vocabulary_highlights: put out a call, our time to shine

speaker: Tim Holley
text: And so using a favorite as an example, you favorite an item. That's a pretty strong ish... Of course, adding it to your cart or maybe purchasing it, that's the strongest of signals, but you've shown intent. So what can we do with that information? We can then say, 'The seller put it on sale. You should come back and check it out.'
text_ko: 예를 들어 누군가 아이템을 즐겨찾기(favorite)했다면, 그건 꽤 강한 신호(signals)예요. 물론 장바구니(cart)에 담거나 실제로 구매하는 건 더 강한 신호지만, 이미 구매 의도(intent)를 보여준 거예요. 그 정보를 가지고 우리는 “판매자가 그 상품을 세일(on sale)로 올렸어요. 다시 와서 확인해 보세요”라고 알릴 수 있어요.
text_zh: 拿收藏这个功能举个例子吧，用户收藏了一个商品，这就是个挺强的信号了...当然了，加购物车或者直接买，那信号就更强了，但收藏已经说明用户有意向了。那我们拿到这个信息能干嘛呢？我们就可以跟用户说："卖家降价了，你回来看看吧。"
text_es: Y entonces, usando el favorito como ejemplo, marcas un artículo como favorito. Esa es una señal bastante fuerte... Claro, agregarlo al carrito o tal vez comprarlo, esas son las señales más fuertes de todas, pero ya mostraste intención. Entonces, ¿qué podemos hacer con esa información? Podemos decirle: "El vendedor lo puso en oferta. Deberías regresar a echarle un vistazo."
context: Lenny asks Tim about what Etsy has learned works effectively for user retention. Tim explains their approach to creating habit loops - when users take actions like favoriting items (similar to 'liking' on other platforms), Etsy uses this behavioral data to create meaningful follow-up touchpoints. For example, if a user favorites an item and the seller later puts it on sale, Etsy can send targeted notifications to bring the user back to complete the purchase, turning initial interest into actual sales.
vocabulary_highlights: pretty strong ish, you've shown intent, come back and check it out

speaker: Tim Holley
text: But I think that it maybe misses the point in some changes or some areas where you are working towards a bigger net new thing or this specific change won't really be indicative of the greater whole you're building towards.
text_ko: 제가 보기에는 어떤 변화들이나 더 큰 완전히 새로운 것(net new thing)을 향해 나아가고 있는 몇몇 영역에서는 이 특정 변화만으로는 여러분이 만들어가고 있는 전체를 잘 보여주지 못해서 핵심을 놓칠 수 있어요.
text_zh: 不过我觉得这样可能有点偏了，特别是在一些变化中，或者当你在朝着一个更大的全新项目努力的时候，这种具体的小改变其实看不出你要搭建的整个大框架是什么样的。
text_es: Pero creo que tal vez se está perdiendo el punto en algunos cambios o en ciertas áreas donde estás trabajando hacia algo completamente nuevo y más grande, o donde este cambio específico realmente no va a ser representativo del conjunto más amplio que estás construyendo.
context: Lenny asks Tim about Etsy's philosophy on experimentation and whether everything runs as an A/B test. Tim acknowledges that while A/B testing provides near absolute certainty about causal relationships between changes and KPIs, it has limitations. He explains that experimentation might not be the best approach when building toward larger, net-new initiatives where individual changes don't represent the full value of what you're creating, suggesting that Etsy is exploring additional validation methods beyond traditional A/B testing.
vocabulary_highlights: misses the point, net new thing, indicative of the greater whole

speaker: Tim Holley
text: The thing that I do a lot, that we do as my team, that others do to some degree is a simple exercise of weekly focus. What are you focused on this week? And then reflecting on, did you get done the things you were focused on last week? Seems super simple, but just the exercise of thinking about what matters, writing it down, and having a little bit of social proof or articulating it out to others creates some degree of accountability.
text_ko: 제가 자주 하고 우리 팀도 하며 다른 분들도 어느 정도 하는 건 간단한 '주간 집중(weekly focus)' 연습이에요. 이번 주에 무엇에 집중하고 있나요? 그리고 지난주에 집중했던 일들을 끝냈는지 되돌아보는 거예요. 정말 단순해 보이지만, 중요한 게 뭔지 생각하고 적어두고 그걸 다른 사람에게 공유해서 일종의 사회적 증거(social proof)를 만들면 자연스럽게 책임감(accountability)이 생겨요.
text_zh: 我经常做的一件事，我们团队也在做，其他人或多或少也会做，就是每周聚焦(weekly focus)这个简单的方法。就是问自己这周要专注做什么？然后回头看看，上周定的那些重点事情你到底做完了没有？听起来特别简单，但就是这么个过程——想想什么事情最重要，把它写下来，再跟别人说说或者有点社会证明(social proof)什么的，这就形成了一定程度的accountability，就是那种责任感和约束力。
text_es: Lo que yo hago mucho, lo que hacemos en mi equipo, y lo que otros también hacen hasta cierto punto, es un ejercicio súper sencillo de enfoque semanal. ¿En qué te vas a enfocar esta semana? Y luego reflexionar sobre si lograste hacer las cosas en las que te enfocaste la semana pasada. Parece súper básico, pero simplemente el ejercicio de pensar en lo que importa, anotarlo, y tener un poquito de prueba social (social proof) o compartirlo con otros crea cierto nivel de rendición de cuentas (accountability).
context: Lenny asks Tim about frameworks or processes he finds particularly useful that listeners might find valuable. Tim describes a simple but effective weekly focus exercise where team members identify their key priorities for the week and then reflect on whether they accomplished the previous week's focus areas. He emphasizes that while this seems basic, the act of writing down priorities and sharing them publicly creates accountability and helps people recognize patterns in their work habits and time estimation over time.
vocabulary_highlights: social proof, articulating it out, creates some degree of accountability

speaker: Timothy Davis
text: Hot take. I would say, paid is for everyone. If you look at the way each platform is doing, Google introducing AI, plus with paid taking up the first four spots, you have to scroll pretty far down to get to an organic listing. Meta, it's almost a pay for play now.
text_ko: 솔직히 말하면요, 제 생각엔 유료 광고(paid)는 이제 모두를 위한 것 같아요. 각 플랫폼을 보면 구글은 인공지능(AI)을 도입했고, 상단 네 자리를 유료 광고(paid)가 차지해서 유기적 노출(organic listing)은 꽤 아래까지 내려가야 볼 수 있어요. 메타는 거의 페이포플레이(pay-for-play)나 다름없어요.
text_zh: 我直说吧，付费推广(paid)现在是人人都得做的。你看各个平台现在什么情况，谷歌加了AI功能，再加上付费广告占了前四个位置，你得往下翻好久才能看到自然排名的结果。Meta那边呢，基本上就是花钱才能玩得转了。
text_es: Opinión controversial. Yo diría que la publicidad pagada es para todos. Si te fijas en cómo está funcionando cada plataforma, Google está introduciendo IA, y además con los anuncios pagados ocupando los primeros cuatro lugares, tienes que hacer scroll bastante para llegar a un resultado orgánico. Meta, ya es casi pagar para jugar (pay for play).
context: Lenny asks whether performance marketing is something every company should be doing or if certain business models should focus on other growth channels like SEO, sales, or word of mouth instead. Timothy argues that the digital landscape has shifted dramatically, making paid advertising essential for virtually all businesses. He explains that organic reach has become increasingly difficult as platforms prioritize paid content, forcing companies to invest in paid channels just to maintain visibility.
vocabulary_highlights: hot take, pay for play

speaker: Timothy Davis
text: Instead of thinking about being on top of the page, and that's like ego marketing, I want to be number one. I want to be there all the time. It's about showing to the right person as often as possible.
text_ko: 페이지 맨 위에만 올라가는 걸 목표로 하는, 이른바 에고 마케팅(ego marketing) 식 사고 대신에 저는 1위를 하고 싶어요. 항상 그 자리에 있고 싶고요. 중요한 건 적절한 사람에게 가능한 한 자주 보이는 거예요.
text_zh: 别老想着要排在搜索结果第一位，那就像是自我炫耀式的营销，什么"我要当老大，我要一直霸占榜首"。关键是要尽可能多地出现在对的人面前。
text_es: En lugar de obsesionarse con estar en la primera posición, que es como marketing de ego, "quiero ser el número uno, quiero estar ahí siempre", se trata de aparecer ante la persona correcta con la mayor frecuencia posible.
context: Lenny asks Timothy about common mistakes he finds when taking over performance marketing accounts from agencies. Timothy explains that many marketers focus on vanity metrics like ranking position rather than targeting effectiveness. He describes 'ego marketing' as the misguided desire to always appear first in search results, when the real goal should be reaching qualified prospects who are likely to convert.
vocabulary_highlights: ego marketing, on top of the page

speaker: Timothy Davis
text: Each platform is different. The user behavior is different. Make sure you're not too hard on yourself if it doesn't work. It's okay to fail because we're either winning or we're learning.
text_ko: 플랫폼(platform)마다 다르고 사용자 행동(user behavior)도 달라요. 잘 안 되면 자신을 너무 몰아붙이지 마세요. 실패해도 괜찮아요, 우리는 이기고 있거나 배우고 있는 거예요.
text_zh: 每个平台都不一样，用户行为也不同。如果效果不好，别对自己太苛刻。失败没关系的，反正我们要么赢，要么学到东西。
text_es: Cada plataforma es distinta. El comportamiento de los usuarios es diferente. Asegúrate de no ser muy duro contigo mismo si no funciona. Está bien fallar porque o estamos ganando o estamos aprendiendo.
context: Lenny asks for tips on experimenting with new advertising platforms to test for signs of life. Timothy advises that marketers should expect some experiments to fail when testing new platforms, as each has unique user behaviors and requirements. He emphasizes the importance of maintaining a learning mindset rather than expecting immediate success, explaining that failed experiments still provide valuable insights for future optimization.
vocabulary_highlights: too hard on yourself, winning or we're learning

speaker: Timothy Davis
text: I always say, where are your users? You will have some data that will allow you to understand that say right now, you're doing really well on TikTok. Some would argue that's an emerging channel right now. Great. If that's doing really well for you, maybe you take... Because that content could be used on something similar like Snap, see how that does for you.
text_ko: 제가 항상 묻는 질문이 있어요. 사용자들이 어디에 있나요? 데이터를 보면 예를 들어 지금 틱톡(TikTok)에서 정말 잘하고 있다는 걸 알 수 있을 거예요. 어떤 사람들은 틱톡을 지금 떠오르는 채널이라고도 말해요. 그게 잘 되고 있다면, 그 콘텐츠를 스냅(Snap) 같은 비슷한 플랫폼에 그대로 써서 반응을 보는 것도 괜찮아요.
text_zh: 我总是这样说，你的用户都在哪儿？你肯定有些数据能让你看出来，比如说现在你在TikTok上做得特别好。有人会说TikTok现在还算是个新兴渠道吧。那挺好的。如果你在那上面效果不错，那你可能可以试试...因为那些内容完全可以放到类似的平台上，比如Snap，看看效果怎么样。
text_es: Siempre digo, ¿dónde están tus usuarios? Vas a tener datos que te van a permitir entender que digamos ahora mismo, te está yendo muy bien en TikTok. Algunos dirían que es un canal emergente en este momento. Perfecto. Si eso te está funcionando súper bien, tal vez puedas tomar... Porque ese contenido se podría usar en algo similar como Snap, a ver qué tal te va ahí.
context: Lenny asks about signs that indicate a company has potential for paid marketing to become most of their growth, rather than just a small percentage. Timothy explains his data-driven approach to identifying promising channels by analyzing existing user behavior patterns. He suggests looking at current traffic sources and user engagement to determine which platforms warrant increased investment, then testing similar platforms that might work with repurposed content.
vocabulary_highlights: emerging channel, turn that knob up to 11

speaker: Timothy Davis
text: The number one thing I tell people all the time is use your own data, start with your own data. So take the existing customer base you have, load that up into the platform to build lookalikes. From there, you can do... And I'll use Meta as the example. You can do a 1%, all the way up to a 10%.
text_ko: 제가 늘 가장 먼저 하는 조언은 자신의 데이터부터 쓰라는 거예요. 이미 보유한 기존 고객 데이터를 플랫폼에 올려서 룩어라이크(lookalikes)를 만들어 보세요. 예를 들면 메타(Meta)에서는 룩어라이크를 1%에서 최대 10%까지 설정할 수 있어요.
text_zh: 我经常跟大家说的第一点就是，用你们自己的数据，从自己的数据开始。把你们现有的客户群导入到平台里，去建立相似受众(lookalikes)。然后呢，我拿Meta举个例子吧，你可以设置1%，一直到10%都行。
text_es: Lo primero que siempre le digo a la gente es que usen sus propios datos, que empiecen con lo que ya tienen. Entonces tomas tu base de clientes actual, la subes a la plataforma para crear audiencias similares (lookalikes). A partir de ahí, puedes hacer... y voy a usar Meta como ejemplo. Puedes hacer desde un 1% hasta un 10%.
context: Lenny asks for advice on running effective 'signs of life' tests when experimenting with new advertising platforms. Timothy recommends starting with lookalike audiences based on existing customer data rather than broad targeting. Lookalike audiences use platform algorithms to find users who behave similarly to a company's current customers, with percentages indicating how closely matched the targeting is - 1% being the most similar and 10% being broader.
vocabulary_highlights: lookalikes, load that up into the platform

speaker: Timothy Davis
text: The biggest thing I want to focus on is what is your thought process when it comes to data? Because I can teach anyone how to do Google ads. I can teach anyone how to do Meta ads. That is not the hard part. It is the data part that is the hard part because there is so much noise going on in those accounts.
text_ko: 제가 가장 중점적으로 보고 싶은 건 데이터(data)를 대할 때 어떤 사고 방식을 가지고 계신가 하는 거예요. 구글 광고(Google Ads)나 메타 광고(Meta Ads)는 누구에게나 가르쳐 줄 수 있어요. 그게 어려운 게 아니에요. 진짜 어려운 건 데이터(data)예요 — 광고 계정(accounts)들에는 잡음(noise)이 너무 많거든요.
text_zh: 我最想重点聊的是，你在处理数据的时候是怎么想的？因为Google广告怎么投、Meta广告怎么做，这些我都能教会任何人，这不是难点。真正难的是数据这块儿，因为那些账户里面杂七杂八的信息太多了，很容易被干扰。
text_es: Lo más importante en lo que me quiero enfocar es: ¿cuál es tu proceso de pensamiento cuando se trata de datos? Porque a cualquier persona le puedo enseñar a hacer anuncios en Google. A cualquier persona le puedo enseñar a hacer anuncios en Meta. Esa no es la parte difícil. La parte difícil son los datos, porque hay muchísimo ruido en esas cuentas.
context: Lenny asks what type of person Timothy looks for when hiring the first performance marketing specialist. Timothy explains his philosophy around hiring data-driven people over those with specific platform experience. He references the book 'The Signal and the Noise' to illustrate how advertising platforms provide overwhelming amounts of metrics, making it crucial to hire someone who can distinguish meaningful insights from irrelevant data points.
vocabulary_highlights: thought process, so much noise going on

speaker: Timothy Davis
text: I'm a big believer in hiring smart people and then getting out of their way. But each week having one-on-ones with them, just spot checking things, just saying, 'Hey, I looked at this. This doesn't look right. What's going on there?' 'Oh yeah, I do that on this day.' 'Okay, great. Just making sure you're covered.'
text_ko: 저는 유능한 사람들을 뽑아서 그냥 맡겨두는 걸 믿어요. 대신 매주 한 번씩 1대1(one-on-one)로 만나서 가볍게 체크만 해요. "이거 제가 봤는데 뭔가 이상해 보여요. 무슨 일인가요?" "아, 그건 이 날에 해요." "아, 좋아요. 그냥 잘 처리되고 있는지 확인하려고요."
text_zh: 我特别相信一点，就是招聪明人，然后别老管着他们。但每周还是要跟他们一对一聊聊，就是随便看看情况，比如说"嗨，我看了一下这个，感觉有点不对劲，怎么回事？""哦对，我那天会处理的。""好的，没问题，就是确认一下你这边都搞定了。"
text_es: Yo creo mucho en contratar gente inteligente y luego dejarles hacer su trabajo. Pero cada semana tengo reuniones uno a uno con ellos, simplemente para revisar cosas, para decir, "Oye, vi esto. No me parece bien. ¿Qué está pasando ahí?" "Ah sí, eso lo hago tal día." "Perfecto. Solo quería asegurarme de que estás cubierto."
context: Lenny asks Timothy to explain why he consistently outperforms agencies when taking over performance marketing accounts. Timothy describes his management philosophy of empowering team members while maintaining oversight through regular check-ins. He contrasts this with agencies that often spread their attention too thin across multiple clients, preventing them from diving deep into account optimization and maintaining consistent quality control.
vocabulary_highlights: getting out of their way, spot checking things

speaker: Tobi Lütke
text: My energy source is dissatisfaction with status quo. My fundamental belief is all this talk about technology where all... So many books are about just technology leading to dystopia. You know what dystopia is? Today, compared to what it will be in 20 years ago or any. I think today is the dystopia of future, and I think it behooves us to try to build the kinds of products that lead in towards progress in a small way or a big way.
text_ko: 제 에너지원은 현상 유지(status quo)에 대한 불만이에요. 제 근본적인 믿음은 기술(technology)에 대한 이야기들이—많은 책들이 기술이 결국 디스토피아(dystopia)로만 이어진다고 말하는—그런 식이라는 거예요. 디스토피아가 뭔지 아세요? 20년 뒤와 비교해 보면 오늘이 바로 그 디스토피아인 셈이에요. 그래서 저는 우리가 작게든 크게든 진보(progress)로 이어지는 제품(products)을 만들려고 노력해야 한다고 생각해요.
text_zh: 我的动力来源就是对现状不满。我有个根本信念，就是现在太多人在谈论技术，太多书都在说技术会导致反乌托邦(dystopia)。你知道什么叫反乌托邦吗？跟20年后比起来，今天就是反乌托邦。我觉得我们有责任去打造那些能推动进步的产品，不管是小小的进步还是大的突破。
text_es: Mi fuente de energía es la insatisfacción con el status quo. Mi creencia fundamental es todo este rollo sobre la tecnología donde... Hay tantos libros que hablan solo de que la tecnología lleva a la distopía. ¿Sabes qué es distopía? El día de hoy, comparado con lo que va a ser en 20 años o cualquier cosa. Yo creo que el presente es la distopía del futuro, y creo que nos conviene tratar de construir el tipo de productos que nos lleven hacia el progreso, ya sea de manera pequeña o grande.
context: Lenny asks Tobi about where he gets his energy as a builder and what drives him. Tobi explains that his energy source is dissatisfaction with the current state of things. He believes that despite all the talk about technology creating dystopia, today is actually primitive compared to what the future holds. This perspective drives him to build products that contribute to human progress rather than accepting the status quo.
vocabulary_highlights: dissatisfaction with status quo, dystopia, it behooves us

speaker: Tobi Lütke
text: There's an aesthetic in the world that exists which is that business people dress in suit and tie, they are speaking much more sophisticated than I do, usually without an accent. They usually have a stick and show dramatically at the chart that is behind them. How much is that aesthetic overlapped with outperformance? Pessimism sounds extremely sophisticated. Optimism always sounds dumb or at least naive. The most powerful unquantifiable things in the word of business are fun and delight.
text_ko: 세상에는 비즈니스 사람들은 정장에 넥타이를 매고 말투도 저보다 훨씬 세련되고 보통 억양도 없이, 막대기를 들고 뒤에 있는 차트를 극적으로 가리키는 그런 미학(aesthetic)이 있어요. 그 이미지가 실제 아웃퍼포먼스(outperformance)랑 얼마나 겹치는 걸까요? 비관은 굉장히 세련되게 들려요. 반대로 낙관은 항상 멍해 보이거나 적어도 순진해 보이는 편이고요. 그런데 비즈니스 세계에서 가장 강력하면서도 수치로는 잡히지 않는 건 결국 재미와 기쁨이에요.
text_zh: 现在商界有这么一种印象，就是商务人士都得西装革履，说话比我高大上多了，通常还没什么口音。他们一般拿个激光笔，在身后的图表前指指点点，演示得特别夸张。但这种范儿跟实际业绩有多大关系呢？悲观主义听起来特别有水平，乐观主义总是显得很傻，至少听着很天真。其实在商业世界里，最有威力但又没法量化的东西就是乐趣和惊喜。
text_es: Hay una estética en el mundo empresarial donde los ejecutivos van de traje y corbata, hablan mucho más sofisticado que yo, normalmente sin acento. Por lo general tienen un puntero y señalan de manera muy dramática el gráfico que tienen detrás. ¿Qué tanto se relaciona esa estética con el rendimiento real? El pesimismo suena súper sofisticado. El optimismo siempre suena tonto, o por lo menos ingenuo. Las cosas más poderosas que no se pueden medir en el mundo de los negocios son la diversión y el deleite.
context: Lenny mentions quotes about how Tobi thinks differently from conventional business approaches. Tobi is explaining how there's a traditional stereotype of what sophisticated business leaders should look and sound like - formal, polished presentations with charts. He questions whether this aesthetic actually correlates with better performance and argues that focusing on unquantifiable elements like fun and delight, though they may sound naive, are actually more powerful than conventional metrics-driven approaches.
vocabulary_highlights: aesthetic, overlapped with outperformance, unquantifiable

speaker: Tobi Lütke
text: At 100 years you can't talk about this software project but you can talk about the mission itself, whatever things that will survive for 80 years that are left on this particular timeframe. Entrepreneurship is just precious. Shopify exists, basically, to make entrepreneurship more common.
text_ko: 100년 후에는 이 소프트웨어 프로젝트 자체를 얘기하긴 어렵지만, 그 미션 자체와 이 특정 기간 안에서 남아 80년은 갈 것들에 대해서는 얘기할 수 있어요. 기업가정신(entrepreneurship)은 정말 소중해요. Shopify는 기본적으로 그런 기업가정신을 더 흔하게 만들기 위해 존재해요.
text_zh: 一百年后，这个软件项目可能就不值一提了，但是我们的使命本身，那些能在这八十年时间里存活下来的东西，还是值得说道的。创业精神太珍贵了。Shopify存在的根本目的，就是让更多人能够创业。
text_es: A los 100 años ya no vas a poder hablar de este proyecto de software, pero sí puedes hablar de la misión en sí, de las cosas que van a perdurar 80 años dentro de ese marco de tiempo. El emprendimiento es algo valioso de verdad. Shopify existe, básicamente, para hacer que emprender sea más común.
context: Lenny asks about Tobi's unique approach of having a 100-year vision that guides product decisions. Tobi explains that while specific software projects won't last 100 years, the underlying mission will endure. He reveals that Shopify's core mission is to make entrepreneurship more accessible and common worldwide. This long-term mission thinking helps guide day-to-day product and business decisions by focusing on what will have lasting impact rather than short-term gains.
vocabulary_highlights: timeframe, precious

speaker: Tobi Lütke
text: I have found that reminding people of their own potential constantly is actually a wonderful thing to do. And I have a history of being right about people's potential more than they are themselves. Now, in a way, this dooms me fairly often to be disappointed, right, in myself. By the way, I'm talking about myself here too. I think I have way more potential than what I bring to bear and I hate that so I'm trying to cultivate the skills that I need for tomorrow and constantly challenge myself.
text_ko: 사람들에게 자신의 잠재력을 계속 상기시켜 주는 일이 사실 정말 좋은 일이라는 걸 알게 됐어요. 그리고 저는 많은 경우 사람들 스스로보다 그들의 잠재력을 더 잘 봐 왔어요. 그래서 자주 제 자신에게 실망하는 운명에 놓이곤 해요. 참고로 저도 제 얘기하는 거예요. 저는 제가 지금 보여주는 것보다 훨씬 더 많은 잠재력이 있다고 생각하고, 그게 너무 싫어서 내일을 위해 필요한 역량을 기르고 끊임없이 스스로에게 도전하고 있어요.
text_zh: 我发现经常提醒别人他们自己的潜力其实是件特别好的事。而且我有个特点，就是我看人的潜力往往比他们自己看得还准。当然了，这样一来我就经常对自己失望，对吧。顺便说一下，我说的这些也包括我自己。我觉得我的潜力远远超过我现在发挥出来的，我很讨厌这种状态，所以我一直在努力培养明天需要的技能，不断挑战自己。
text_es: He descubierto que recordarle constantemente a la gente su propio potencial es algo realmente valioso. Y tengo un historial de acertar más sobre el potencial de las personas que ellas mismas. Claro, esto me condena bastante seguido a sentirme decepcionado, ¿no?, conmigo mismo. Por cierto, aquí también hablo de mí. Creo que tengo mucho más potencial del que realmente aprovecho y eso me molesta, así que estoy tratando de desarrollar las habilidades que necesito para el futuro y desafiarme constantemente.
context: Lenny asks about Tobi's direct feedback style and how it relates to maximizing human potential. Tobi explains his belief that no one is close to reaching their maximum potential. He describes how he constantly reminds people of their untapped capabilities, often seeing potential in others that they don't see in themselves. He admits this approach sometimes leads to disappointment when people don't reach the heights he believes they can achieve, and he applies this same high standard to himself.
vocabulary_highlights: reminding people of their own potential, dooms me, bring to bear, cultivate the skills

speaker: Tobi Lütke
text: If you want to do something better than what exists, you have to do it differently. That does not make a statement about if it will be better in the end after you do it. It could also be worse. But you can't get something better done if you do the same thing. It's like axiomatically not possible to do.
text_ko: 기존 것보다 더 잘하려면 방식 자체를 달리해야 해요. 다르게 한다고 해서 결국 더 좋아질 거라고 단정할 수는 없어요. 오히려 더 나빠질 수도 있어요. 하지만 같은 방식으로는 더 나은 결과를 얻을 수 없어요 — 원리적으로(axiomatically) 불가능해요.
text_zh: 你要是想做得比现有的更好，那就得换个做法。这不是说你换了做法最后就一定会更好，也有可能更糟。但是你要是还是老一套的话，肯定做不出更好的东西来。这基本上就是不可能的事儿。
text_es: Si quieres hacer algo mejor de lo que ya existe, tienes que hacerlo de manera diferente. Eso no garantiza que al final vaya a quedar mejor después de que lo hagas. También puede salir peor. Pero no puedes lograr algo mejor si haces exactamente lo mismo. Es como que axiomáticamente es imposible.
context: Lenny shares quotes about how Tobi avoids doing things the conventional way, asking him to elaborate on this thinking. Tobi explains this as a fundamental logical principle - if you want to create something superior to existing solutions, you must approach it differently by definition. He acknowledges that different doesn't guarantee better results, but emphasizes that doing the same thing as everyone else axiomatically cannot produce superior outcomes.
vocabulary_highlights: axiomatically not possible

speaker: Tobi Lütke
text: Every product in the world, the quality at the end of the day is simply a reflection of how much the people who created it gave a shit about the product. And it is not possible to make great products if the people work on it do not give a shit about the product. And I actually think this is a very important role for product leaders to make sure that the team gives a shit.
text_ko: 결국 세상의 모든 제품 품질은 그 제품을 만든 사람들이 얼마나 신경을 썼는지를 그대로 반영해요. 그리고 그 제품에 신경을 쓰지 않는 사람들이 일한다면 훌륭한 제품을 만들 수 없어요. 사실 팀이 제품에 진심으로 신경 쓰게 만드는 건 프로덕트 리더(product leaders)의 아주 중요한 역할이라고 생각해요.
text_zh: 世界上任何产品，说到底质量好坏就是看做产品的人到底有多在乎这个产品。如果团队的人对产品都不上心，那肯定做不出好产品来。我觉得产品负责人有个很重要的职责，就是要让整个团队都真正在乎这个产品。
text_es: Todos los productos del mundo, al final del día la calidad simplemente refleja qué tanto les importó el producto a las personas que lo crearon. Y es imposible hacer productos geniales si a la gente que trabaja en ellos no les importa un carajo el producto. Y creo que este es un rol súper importante para los líderes de producto: asegurarse de que al equipo realmente le importe.
context: As the interview concludes, Lenny asks if there's anything final Tobi wants to share with listeners. Tobi offers advice specifically for product managers and leaders. He argues that product quality fundamentally comes down to how much the creators care about what they're building. He emphasizes that great products cannot be created by teams that don't genuinely care, and makes it clear that product leaders have a crucial role in ensuring their teams are genuinely invested in and passionate about the products they're developing.
vocabulary_highlights: gave a shit about, infectiously

speaker: Todd Jackson
text: And all the advice that you find out there on the internet is very general when it comes to product-market fit. You'll know it when you see it, you'll know it when you have it. It's not specific. And there's so many other startup topics where there is good content on the internet like hiring your first salesperson, running board meetings, stuff that is specific and tactical.
text_ko: 인터넷에 널린 조언들은 제품-시장 적합성(product-market fit)에 관해서는 거의 대부분 너무 일반적이에요. 한 번 보면 알게 되고, 실제로 갖고 있으면 알게 되긴 하는데 구체적인 건 아니죠. 반면에 첫 영업사원 채용이나 이사회 운영 같은 다른 스타트업 관련 주제들은 인터넷에 구체적이고 실무적인 좋은 콘텐츠가 정말 많아요.
text_zh: 网上关于产品市场匹配(product-market fit)的建议都特别泛泛而谈。什么"你有感觉的时候自然就知道了"，"找到了你就明白了"，一点都不具体。可是其他很多创业话题，网上都有很不错的干货内容，比如怎么招第一个销售，怎么开董事会，这些都很具体很实用。
text_es: Y todos los consejos que encuentras por ahí en internet sobre el encaje producto-mercado (product-market fit) son súper generales. Te dicen "lo vas a saber cuando lo veas", "te vas a dar cuenta cuando lo tengas". No es nada específico. Y hay tantos otros temas de startups donde sí hay buen contenido en internet, como contratar a tu primer vendedor, manejar juntas de consejo, cosas que sí son específicas y prácticas.
context: Lenny asks Todd why founders need a framework for finding product-market fit and why it's so important. Todd explains that product-market fit advice is typically vague and mysterious, unlike other startup topics that have specific, actionable guidance. He argues that while other areas like hiring or board meetings have detailed, tactical content available, product-market fit remains poorly explained despite being the most critical challenge for early-stage companies.
vocabulary_highlights: stuff that is specific and tactical

speaker: Todd Jackson
text: Finding product-market fit is the single most important thing that your startup does in the first three years, and it's just underexplored and it's just underexplained as a topic. So we felt this was a very important thing to do, something worth focusing on.
text_ko: 제품-시장 적합성(product-market fit)을 찾는 건 스타트업이 처음 3년 동안 하는 일 중에서 가장 중요한 일이에요. 그런데 이 주제는 충분히 탐구되지도 않았고, 제대로 설명된 적도 별로 없어요. 그래서 저희는 이걸 꼭 다뤄야 할 중요한 주제로 보고 집중할 가치가 있다고 생각했어요.
text_zh: 找到产品市场匹配度(product-market fit)是你们创业公司头三年最重要的事儿，没有之一。但这个话题研究得太少了，也没人好好讲清楚过。所以我们觉得这事儿特别重要，值得花心思去做。
text_es: Lograr el ajuste producto-mercado (product-market fit) es lo más importante que puede hacer tu startup en los primeros tres años, y es un tema que está súper poco explorado y mal explicado. Por eso sentimos que era algo muy importante de hacer, algo en lo que valía la pena enfocarse.
context: Todd is explaining why he and First Round Capital developed their product-market fit framework. He emphasizes that despite being the most critical milestone for startups in their early years, product-market fit lacks comprehensive, actionable guidance compared to other business topics. This knowledge gap motivated them to create a systematic approach to help founders navigate this crucial challenge.
vocabulary_highlights: underexplored, underexplained

speaker: Todd Jackson
text: Because if you find extreme product-market fit, the momentum just carries you, and the market pulls you along. And it's easy to know what to build because you're building the thing that your customers want and it's motivating as a team. It's easy to hire people, everything becomes easier if you find product-market fit, it is the thing that propels the company.
text_ko: 압도적인 제품-시장 적합성(product-market fit)을 찾으면 추진력이 저절로 따라와서 시장이 회사를 끌고 가요. 고객들이 진짜 원하는 걸 만드는 거니까 뭘 만들어야 할지도 명확하고, 팀도 훨씬 의욕이 생겨요. 채용도 쉬워지고, 모든 게 더 수월해져요. 제품-시장 적합성 자체가 회사를 앞으로 밀어주는 힘이에요.
text_zh: 因为一旦你找到了极佳的产品市场契合度(product-market fit)，那种势头就会推着你往前走，市场会拉着你跑。而且你很清楚该做什么产品，因为你在做的就是客户真正想要的东西，这对团队来说特别有动力。招人也变得容易，有了产品市场契合度，什么事都变简单了，这就是推动公司发展的核心动力。
text_es: Porque si logras un encaje producto-mercado (product-market fit) increíble, el impulso te lleva solo, y el mercado te jala. Y es súper fácil saber qué construir porque estás haciendo exactamente lo que tus clientes quieren, y eso motiva un montón al equipo. Es más fácil contratar gente, todo se vuelve más sencillo cuando encuentras ese encaje producto-mercado (product-market fit), es lo que realmente impulsa la empresa.
context: Lenny asks Todd to elaborate on why product-market fit is so critical for founders to focus on. Todd describes how achieving strong product-market fit creates a virtuous cycle where market forces work in the company's favor. He explains that when customers truly want your product, it simplifies decision-making across all business functions - from product development to hiring - because the market demand provides clear direction and momentum.
vocabulary_highlights: the momentum just carries you, the market pulls you along, propels the company

speaker: Todd Jackson
text: We can't guarantee success here. I just want to contextualize that finding extreme product-market fit is very, very hard. And what we are trying to do is increase your odds, increase the odds, reduce the role of luck, give you a framework and way of thinking about the things that you need to do.
text_ko: 여기서 성공을 보장할 수는 없어요. 다만 극단적인 제품-시장 적합성(product-market fit)을 찾아내는 건 정말, 정말 어렵다는 맥락을 설명드리고 싶어요. 우리가 하려는 건 성공 확률을 높여드리고, 운의 역할을 줄여드리며, 해야 할 일들에 대해 생각할 수 있는 프레임워크(framework)와 사고방식(way of thinking)을 제공하는 거예요.
text_zh: 我们不能保证一定成功哈。我想先说清楚，要找到特别好的产品市场匹配(product-market fit)真的是超级难的事儿。我们现在要做的就是提高你们成功的概率，减少运气的成分，给你们一套框架和思路，让你们知道该怎么去做这些事情。
text_es: No podemos garantizar el éxito aquí. Solo quiero poner en contexto que lograr un product-market fit extremo es súper, súper difícil. Y lo que estamos tratando de hacer es aumentar tus probabilidades, mejorar las chances, reducir el papel de la suerte, darte un marco de trabajo y una forma de pensar sobre las cosas que necesitas hacer.
context: Lenny asks Todd about the realistic benefits and outcomes founders can expect from following this product-market fit framework. Todd provides an honest assessment, emphasizing that no framework can guarantee success in what remains an extremely challenging endeavor. He positions their approach as a way to improve probability of success rather than a silver bullet, focusing on systematic thinking over relying purely on chance.
vocabulary_highlights: contextualize, increase your odds, reduce the role of luck

speaker: Todd Jackson
text: But the interesting thing is that you don't go for all three of them from the very beginning. And so product-market fit, it happens in the sequence of levels, it happens over multiple years. And for the best enterprise companies, I would say they tend to reach extreme product-market fit in roughly four to six years.
text_ko: 재미있는 건 처음부터 세 가지를 모두 한꺼번에 노리지는 않는다는 점이에요. 제품-시장 적합성(product-market fit)은 단계별로, 여러 해에 걸쳐 서서히 찾아와요. 저는 최고의 엔터프라이즈 기업들(enterprise companies)이 보통 대략 4~6년 정도에 아주 강한 제품-시장 적합성에 도달한다고 봐요.
text_zh: 但有意思的是，你不可能一开始就把这三个方面都搞定。所以产品市场匹配(product-market fit)嘛，它是分层次、分阶段来的，需要好几年时间。对于那些最牛的企业级公司来说，我觉得他们一般要花个四到六年左右才能达到极致的产品市场匹配(product-market fit)。
text_es: Pero lo interesante es que no vas por los tres desde el primer día. Entonces el product-market fit, pasa por niveles, en secuencia, lleva varios años. Y para las mejores empresas B2B, yo diría que tienden a alcanzar un product-market fit extremo en unos cuatro a seis años aproximadamente.
context: Todd is explaining his framework's three key dimensions of product-market fit: demand, satisfaction, and efficiency. He's clarifying that companies don't need to optimize all three dimensions simultaneously from day one. Instead, product-market fit develops progressively through distinct levels over several years, with the most successful enterprise companies typically achieving the highest level within four to six years of founding.
vocabulary_highlights: sequence of levels, roughly four to six years

speaker: Todd Jackson
text: And the reason that she needed to get it is because we wanted to start selling Dropbox Paper into enterprise. And so she said to me, 'There's this pain out there, I think I can solve it, and I think there might be a revenue unlock.' And I was like, 'What do you mean by that?' And she was like, 'Well, I've got these first few customers or design partner, pseudo customers.'
text_ko: 그녀가 이걸 꼭 가져와야 했던 이유는 우리가 Dropbox Paper를 기업에 판매하기 시작하고 싶었기 때문이에요. 그래서 그녀가 저한테 '이런 문제들이 있는데, 내가 해결할 수 있을 것 같고, 수익을 창출할 수 있는 기회가 있을 것 같아'라고 말했어요. 제가 '그게 무슨 뜻이에요?'라고 물어보니까, 그녀가 '음, 몇몇 초기 고객이나 디자인 파트너, 가짜 고객들이 있어'라고 했어요.
text_zh: 她之前需要拿到这个认证，是因为我们想把Dropbox Paper卖给企业客户。然后她就跟我说，"市场上有这个痛点，我觉得我能解决，而且我觉得这可能是个赚钱的机会。"我就问她，"你这话是什么意思？"她说，"我已经有了几个初期客户，或者说设计合作伙伴(design partner)，算是准客户吧。"
text_es: Y la razón por la que necesitaba conseguirlo es porque queríamos empezar a vender Dropbox Paper a empresas grandes. Entonces me dice: "Hay un problema ahí afuera, creo que lo puedo resolver, y pienso que podría generar ingresos nuevos (revenue unlock)." Y yo le digo: "¿A qué te refieres con eso?" Y me contesta: "Bueno, ya tengo estos primeros clientes o socios de diseño (design partners), como clientes potenciales."
context: Todd is sharing the origin story of Vanta as an example of level one product-market fit. He's describing how founder Christina Cacioppo discovered the compliance automation opportunity while working at Dropbox. Christina realized that SOC 2 certification was blocking enterprise sales deals, and she identified this as both a painful problem and a potential revenue unlock for her target customers who were trying to sell into Fortune 500 companies.
vocabulary_highlights: revenue unlock, design partner, pseudo customers

speaker: Tom Conrad
text: There's this belief that everybody needs to be a founder. I think, in some ways, our industry would be much better off if there were fewer founders. There's an entire category of smart, creative, hardworking, talented, borderline visionary people who can raise that $2 million seed and go off and build some stupid company that's never going to go anywhere. That would be so much better off finding a team that needs their skillset and working on a problem that has a mathematical formula that's going to win on any metric.
text_ko: 모두가 창업자(founder)가 돼야 한다는 믿음이 있죠. 개인적으로는 어떤 면에서는 우리 업계가 창업자(founder)가 좀 더 적었으면 훨씬 나을 것 같아요. 똑똑하고 창의적이고 열심히 일하고 재능 있는, 거의 비전가(visionary)에 가까운 사람들이 있는데도 그런 사람들이 200만 달러짜리 시드(seed) 자금을 모아서 결국 성공할 가능성이 거의 없는 쓸데없는 회사를 만드는 경우가 많아요. 그보다는 자신의 스킬셋(skillset)이 필요한 팀을 찾아가서 모든 지표(metric)에서 통할 수 있는 수학적 공식(mathematical formula)이 있는 문제를 해결하는 데 합류하는 게 훨씬 나을 거예요.
text_zh: 现在有个观念就是人人都得当创始人。我觉得，从某种程度上说，如果创始人少一点，咱们这个行业反而会更好。有一大批聪明、有创意、勤奋、有才华、甚至可以说有远见的人，他们能拉到200万美元的种子轮融资，然后跑去搞一些没前途的破公司。其实这些人如果能找个需要他们技能的团队，去解决那些有明确成功公式、在各项指标上都能赢的问题，那效果会好得多。
text_es: Existe esta creencia de que todo mundo tiene que ser fundador. Yo creo que, de cierta manera, nuestra industria estaría mucho mejor si hubiera menos fundadores. Hay toda una categoría de gente inteligente, creativa, trabajadora, talentosa, casi visionaria, que puede levantar esos 2 millones de capital semilla (seed) y largarse a crear alguna empresa estúpida que nunca va a llegar a ningún lado. Esa gente estaría mucho mejor si encontrara un equipo que necesite sus habilidades y trabajara en un problema que tenga una fórmula matemática que vaya a ganar en cualquier métrica.
context: This is Tom Conrad's contrarian take from later in the episode when Lenny asks him to share an unpopular opinion he holds. Tom argues against the prevalent startup culture belief that everyone should become a founder. He believes many talented people waste their potential starting companies destined to fail instead of joining existing teams with better business fundamentals and market opportunities.
vocabulary_highlights: borderline visionary, mathematical formula that's going to win, go off and build

speaker: Tom Conrad
text: I think the thing I've come to better appreciate is that companies are also like a math problem that describes how you take investment and pour them into the equation and out the other side comes returns on some time horizon. But if the equation is fundamentally broken or a big swing in and of itself, no amount of iteration and execution can get you out of the failed outputs of the broken equation.
text_ko: 제가 새삼 더 잘 느낀 건, 회사도 결국 투자(investment)를 수식(equation)에 넣으면 일정 기간(time horizon) 뒤에 수익(returns)이 나오는 수학 문제 같다는 점이에요. 그런데 그 수식 자체가 근본적으로 잘못됐거나 자체적으로 큰 요동을 보인다면, 아무리 반복(iteration)하고 실행(execution)해도 망가진 수식이 만들어내는 실패한 결과에서 벗어날 수 없어요.
text_zh: 我觉得现在更能理解的是，公司其实就像一道数学题——你把投资投进去，经过一段时间后另一头就出来回报。但是如果这个公式本身就有问题，或者本身就是个大赌注，那不管你怎么调整优化、怎么拼命执行，都救不了这个坏公式算出来的烂结果。
text_es: Creo que lo que he llegado a entender mejor es que las empresas son como un problema matemático que describe cómo tomas la inversión y la metes en la ecuación, y del otro lado salen los retornos en cierto plazo. Pero si la ecuación está fundamentalmente rota o es una apuesta muy arriesgada en sí misma, por más que iteres y ejecutes, no vas a poder salir de los resultados fallidos de esa ecuación quebrada.
context: Tom is reflecting on lessons learned from his experience at Quibi when Lenny asks what he took away from that notable failure. Tom explains how his perspective on companies evolved - he used to focus primarily on product execution, but now understands that companies operate according to fundamental business model equations. If the core math doesn't work, even perfect product execution cannot save the company.
vocabulary_highlights: pour them into the equation, big swing in and of itself, failed outputs of the broken equation

speaker: Tom Conrad
text: One super interesting thing that no one talks about is that all of that content was designed to be made day of or day before it aired, so there was no back catalog of it. And it was all designed to be shot in these professional studios that we built out. It was really expensive, like I said, it was like a third of the investment we were going to making content, almost half the investment we were going to be making content.
text_ko: 아무도 잘 말하지 않는 되게 흥미로운 점 하나는, 그 모든 콘텐츠가 방송 당일이나 전날에 제작되도록 설계돼 있어서 쌓아둔 백카탈로그(back catalog)가 전혀 없었다는 거예요. 그리고 그 모든 게 우리가 직접 구축한 전문 스튜디오에서 촬영하도록 만들어졌고요. 비용이 정말 많이 들었어요. 앞서 말했듯이, 그게 콘텐츠 제작에 투입하려던 투자액의 대략 3분의 1, 심지어 거의 절반에 달할 정도였어요.
text_zh: 有个特别有意思的事儿，大家都没怎么聊过，就是那些内容全都是设计成当天或者前一天拍完就播的，根本没有什么内容库存。而且全都得在我们搭建的专业演播室里拍摄。成本真的很高，我刚才说了，差不多占了我们内容投资的三分之一，甚至快一半了。
text_es: Una cosa súper interesante de la que nadie habla es que todo ese contenido estaba diseñado para hacerse el mismo día o el día anterior a su transmisión, así que no había ningún archivo previo. Y todo estaba pensado para grabarse en estos estudios profesionales que montamos. Era carísimo, como te digo, era como un tercio de la inversión que íbamos a hacer en contenido, casi la mitad de la inversión que íbamos a destinar al contenido.
context: Tom is explaining what went wrong with Quibi's business model when they launched during COVID. He's describing how they had planned to create daily content in professional studios as a key differentiator from YouTube content, but the pandemic forced them to produce content from hosts' garages, undermining their value proposition and making their content indistinguishable from typical YouTube productions.
vocabulary_highlights: back catalog, day of or day before it aired

speaker: Tom Conrad
text: When I met our early audience in an incredibly genuine way. For example, when we launched the support@pandora.com was an alias for all@pandora.com. So if you sent a customer service request to Pandora, every single person in the company received it. And because we made a decision to have no customer support team in the first year, the expectation was that whoever sees the request first should respond to it.
text_ko: 초기 고객층과 정말 진심으로 소통했어요. 예를 들어 런칭할 때 support@pandora.com을 all@pandora.com의 별칭(alias)으로 설정해뒀어요. 그래서 누군가 Pandora에 고객 문의를 보내면 회사에 있는 모든 사람이 그 메일을 받았어요. 그리고 첫 해에는 고객 지원팀을 따로 두지 않기로 해서, 그 요청을 가장 먼저 본 사람이 답을 하기로 되어 있었어요.
text_zh: 我们刚开始的时候是真心实意地和早期用户打交道的。比如说，我们刚上线的时候，support@pandora.com其实就是all@pandora.com的别名。所以你要是给潘多拉发个客服邮件，公司里每个人都能收到。而且我们当时决定第一年不设专门的客服团队，就是谁先看到邮件谁就回复。
text_es: Cuando conecté con nuestra audiencia inicial de una manera súper auténtica. Por ejemplo, cuando lanzamos, el support@pandora.com era básicamente lo mismo que all@pandora.com. O sea, si mandabas una consulta de atención al cliente a Pandora, absolutamente toda la gente de la empresa la recibía. Y como decidimos no tener un equipo de atención al cliente el primer año, la cosa era que el que viera primero la consulta, esa persona tenía que responderla.
context: Tom is sharing lessons from Pandora's early success when Lenny asks about what he learned from that experience. He's explaining how they built genuine relationships with users in the early days by having every employee handle customer support directly, without scripts or restrictions, which helped create authentic word-of-mouth growth that powered Pandora from zero to 80 million users without any paid acquisition.
vocabulary_highlights: in an incredibly genuine way, was an alias for, whoever sees the request first

speaker: Tom Conrad
text: I think we just completely misjudged one really important thing, which is that we were really inspired by disrupting terrestrial radio. Terrestrial radio is the predominant form of music consumption in the country. People spend, I can't remember the exact stats, but by minutes consumed, it's something like 10 times more music minutes a month on radio in the aughts and early tens than on owned music.
text_ko: 우리는 한 가지를 완전히 잘못 판단한 것 같아요. 지상파 라디오(terrestrial radio)를 흔들어놓는 데서 많이 영감을 받았는데, 그 라디오는 이 나라에서 음악 소비의 주된 방식이었어요. 정확한 수치는 기억이 안 나지만, 재생 시간(분 기준)으로 보면 2000년대와 2010년대 초반에는 한 달에 라디오에서 소비되는 음악 시간이 소유 음악(owned music)보다 대략 10배 정도 많았던 것 같아요.
text_zh: 我觉得我们完全看错了一个特别重要的点，就是我们当时特别想颠覆传统电台。传统电台是这个国家音乐消费的主要方式。人们花在听电台上的时间，我记不清具体数字了，但按分钟数算，在2000年代和2010年代初，每个月听电台音乐的时间比听自己买的音乐要多大概10倍。
text_es: Creo que nos equivocamos completamente con algo súper importante: estábamos obsesionados con revolucionar la radio tradicional. La radio tradicional es como la gente consume música principalmente en el país. La gente pasa, no me acuerdo de las cifras exactas, pero por minutos consumidos, es como 10 veces más minutos de música al mes en radio en los 2000 y principios de los 2010 que en música propia.
context: Lenny asks Tom if there was a path for Pandora to become like Spotify and avoid being disrupted. Tom explains that Pandora's strategic mistake was focusing on disrupting terrestrial radio rather than the owned music market. They believed the radio advertising market was larger and less competitive, but this positioning put them at odds with record labels who preferred the Spotify subscription model.
vocabulary_highlights: completely misjudged, disrupting terrestrial radio, predominant form, by minutes consumed

speaker: Tom Conrad
text: While companies are definitely the software that they make and the products that they deliver and that there is an art and science to that, as I described, there is also, if you step back, there is an equation that describes the business. It talks about how you turn investment into returns. And I suppose if I had come up with finance and been a business major that maybe that's the way that I would've conceived of companies to begin with.
text_ko: 회사는 분명히 그들이 만드는 소프트웨어(software)와 제공하는 제품(products)이에요. 제가 설명한 대로 그 일에는 예술이자 과학(art and science)이 있죠. 하지만 한 걸음 물러나 보면 사업을 설명하는 수식(equation)이 있어요. 그 수식은 투자를 어떻게 수익(returns)으로 바꾸는지를 말해요. 만약 제가 금융학(finance)을 배우고 경영학 전공(business major)이었다면, 아마 애초부터 회사를 그렇게 생각했을 거예요.
text_zh: 公司当然就是他们开发的软件和交付的产品，这里面确实有技术和艺术的成分，就像我刚说的那样。但是你往后退一步看，其实有个公式可以描述这个生意本质，就是怎么把投资变成回报。我觉得如果我当初学的是金融，读商科出身的话，可能一开始就会这么看公司了。
text_es: Mira, las empresas obviamente son el software que desarrollan y los productos que entregan, y sí hay todo un arte y ciencia detrás de eso, como te decía, pero si das un paso atrás, también hay una ecuación que describe el negocio. Te explica cómo conviertes la inversión en retornos. Y supongo que si hubiera estudiado finanzas o hubiera sido especialista en negocios, tal vez esa habría sido mi forma de entender las empresas desde el principio.
context: Tom is sharing what he's learned as a first-time CEO at Zero, his current health and longevity company. Lenny asks what he's learned as CEO that he wishes he knew as a product leader. Tom explains how his perspective evolved from seeing companies primarily as product and engineering challenges to understanding the fundamental business equations that drive success or failure.
vocabulary_highlights: step back, conceived of companies, turn investment into returns

speaker: Tomer Cohen
speaker_expertise: AI/ML Products, Product Management, User Experience
text: When we look at the skills required to do your job, by 2030, it will change by 70%. So whether or not you're looking to change your job, your job is changing. In order to stay competitive, you actually have to go back to some first principles, go back to the drawing board and reimagine what it means to be building.
text_ko: 여러분의 일을 해내는 데 필요한 스킬은 2030년까지 약 70%가 바뀔 거예요. 그래서 이직을 고려하든 안 하든, 지금 하고 있는 일이 변하고 있다는 뜻이에요. 경쟁력을 유지하려면 기본 원리(first principles)로 돌아가 백지에서 다시 시작하듯 도면을 다시 그려보고, ‘무엇을 만드는 것(building)’이 무엇인지 다시 상상해봐야 해요.
