text_zh: 你看啊，到2030年的时候，你现在这份工作需要的技能会有70%都变掉。所以不管你想不想换工作，反正工作本身已经在变了。想要保持竞争力，你得回到最基本的原理上，重新来过，重新思考什么叫做"建设"。
text_es: Cuando miramos las habilidades que vas a necesitar para tu trabajo, para el 2030 van a cambiar en un 70%. O sea que quieras cambiar de trabajo o no, tu trabajo se está transformando. Para mantenerte competitivo, en realidad tienes que volver a lo básico, empezar desde cero y replantearte completamente lo que significa construir.
context: Lenny asks Tomer why he decided to completely rethink how product development works at LinkedIn and why other leaders need to pay attention to this transformation. Tomer explains that LinkedIn has unique visibility into the changing nature of work, and their data shows that 70% of the skills required for any given job will change by 2030. This rapid pace of change means companies must fundamentally reimagine their approach to building products to stay competitive.
vocabulary_highlights: go back to some first principles, go back to the drawing board, reimagine what it means to be building

speaker: Tomer Cohen
speaker_expertise: AI/ML Products, Product Management, User Experience
text: We call it the full stack builder model. The goal itself is to empower great builders to take their idea and to take it to market, regardless of their role and the stack and which team they're on. It's really fluid interaction between human and machine.
text_ko: 우리는 그걸 풀스택 빌더 모델(full stack builder model)이라고 불러요. 목표는 훌륭한 빌더들이 자신의 아이디어를 어떤 역할을 맡고 있든, 어떤 스택(stack)을 쓰고 있든, 어떤 팀에 속해 있든 상관없이 아이디어를 실현해 시장에 내놓을 수 있도록 역량을 실어 주는 거예요. 사람과 기계가 유연하게 상호작용하는 방식이에요.
text_zh: 我们叫它全栈构建者模式(full stack builder model)。目标就是让那些厉害的构建者能够把自己的想法推向市场，不管他们在哪个岗位、用什么技术栈(stack)、在哪个团队。这其实就是人和机器之间很流畅的互动。
text_es: Lo llamamos el modelo de constructor integral (full stack builder). El objetivo en sí es empoderar a los grandes constructores para que tomen su idea y la lleven al mercado, sin importar cuál sea su rol, en qué parte del stack estén o en qué equipo trabajen. Es realmente una interacción fluida entre el humano y la máquina.
context: Lenny asks Tomer to explain the name and concept of the new program LinkedIn has developed. The full stack builder model is LinkedIn's radical approach to product development that enables individual contributors to take products from idea to launch regardless of their traditional function. Unlike traditional teams where product managers, designers, and engineers work in sequence, this model creates a seamless collaboration between humans and AI tools.
vocabulary_highlights: full stack builder model, take it to market, fluid interaction

speaker: Tomer Cohen
speaker_expertise: AI/ML Products, Product Management, User Experience
text: Change management here is going to be a critical part, but it's not enough to give them the tools. You have to build the incentives programs, the motivation, the examples to how you do it. I see a lot of companies roll out their agents and just expecting companies to adopt. It doesn't work this way.
text_ko: 여기서 변화 관리(change management)는 핵심인데, 도구만 주는 것으로는 부족해요. 인센티브 프로그램(incentive programs)과 동기 부여, 어떻게 하는지 보여주는 사례들을 만들어야 해요. 많은 회사들이 에이전트(agents)를 배포해 놓고 알아서 채택되길 기대하는데, 그렇게 되지 않아요.
text_zh: 变革管理(change management)在这里会是关键一环，但光给他们工具还不够。你得建立激励机制、调动积极性，还要给出具体的操作示例。我看到很多公司就是把代理工具(agents)一推出去，就指望企业会自动采用。这样搞肯定不行的。
text_es: La gestión del cambio va a ser clave aquí, pero no basta con darles las herramientas. Tienes que crear programas de incentivos, la motivación, ejemplos de cómo hacerlo. Veo muchas empresas que lanzan sus agentes y simplemente esperan que las compañías los adopten. Así no funciona la cosa.
context: Lenny observes that top performers are finding the most success with AI tools and asks about adoption challenges. Tomer explains that simply providing AI tools to employees isn't sufficient for organizational transformation. He emphasizes that successful adoption requires comprehensive change management including performance incentives, motivational programs, and concrete examples of success. He notes that many companies fail by just deploying AI agents without supporting the cultural shift needed for adoption.
vocabulary_highlights: roll out their agents, just expecting companies to adopt

speaker: Tomer Cohen
speaker_expertise: AI/ML Products, Product Management, User Experience
text: Top talent has this tendency of continuously trying to get better at their craft. The key trait that I'm emphasizing for builders is where I want them to spend their time is where I think great builders should shine in.
text_ko: 최고 인재들은 자신의 실력을 계속해서 더 나아지게 하려는 경향이 있어요. 제가 빌더들(builders)에게 특히 강조하는 핵심은 그들이 시간을 어디에 쓰느냐인데, 바로 그 지점에서 훌륭한 빌더들이 빛나야 한다고 생각해요.
text_zh: 顶尖人才都有一个特点，就是会不断地想要在自己的专业领域做得更好。我特别看重做产品的人(builders)的一个品质，就是我希望他们把时间花在真正能让优秀产品人发光发热的地方。
text_es: El talento de primera tiene esa tendencia de siempre estar tratando de mejorar en lo suyo. La característica clave que les recalco a los que construyen es en qué quiero que inviertan su tiempo, ahí es donde creo que los grandes constructores realmente deben brillar.
context: Lenny questions whether AI makes average people better or makes great people even better. Tomer confirms that LinkedIn's top performers are the most successful with their new AI-powered tools, explaining that high performers naturally seek to improve their craft and stay at the cutting edge. He then transitions to describing the specific traits he wants builders to focus on - vision, empathy, communication, creativity, and judgment - rather than automatable tasks.
vocabulary_highlights: get better at their craft, shine in

speaker: Tomer Cohen
speaker_expertise: AI/ML Products, Product Management, User Experience
text: We ended up building our own trust agent at LinkedIn. So when you build a spec, you build an idea, you walk through the trust agent and it'll basically tell you what are your vulnerabilities, what harm vectors potentially you're introducing or will be introduced as a result of that.
text_ko: 결국 LinkedIn에서 저희만의 트러스트 에이전트(trust agent)를 만들게 되었어요. 그래서 스펙(spec)을 만들거나 아이디어를 구체화할 때 그 에이전트로 쭉 검토해 보면, 어떤 취약점이 있는지와 그로 인해 어떤 피해 벡터(harm vectors)가 생기거나 유발될 수 있는지를 알려줘요.
text_zh: 我们最后在LinkedIn自己搭建了一个信任代理(trust agent)。所以当你在做规划、构思想法的时候，你把这些过一遍信任代理，它基本上就能告诉你有哪些漏洞，可能会带来什么样的风险点，或者说因为这个决定可能会产生什么隐患。
text_es: Terminamos creando nuestro propio agente de confianza en LinkedIn. Entonces, cuando armas una especificación, cuando desarrollas una idea, la pasas por el agente de confianza y básicamente te dice cuáles son tus vulnerabilidades, qué vectores de daño (harm vectors) potencialmente estás introduciendo o que se van a introducir como resultado de eso.
context: Lenny asks about the specific AI agents LinkedIn has built to automate parts of product development. Tomer explains that LinkedIn couldn't use off-the-shelf AI tools and had to build custom agents tailored to their specific needs. The trust agent is one example - it analyzes product specifications and identifies potential security vulnerabilities and harm vectors that could affect users. This agent was built by LinkedIn's head of trust and incorporates all their unique trust considerations.
vocabulary_highlights: trust agent, harm vectors

speaker: Tomer Cohen
speaker_expertise: AI/ML Products, Product Management, User Experience
text: Whether you're in an organization, you're waiting for your leader to roll this out or you're a leader trying to roll this out, I would not wait. If you're looking for a formal reorg or declaration to start building differently, you're waiting too long.
text_ko: 조직 안에서 리더가 이걸 도입(roll out)해 주길 기다리든, 리더로서 직접 도입하려 하든, 저는 기다리지 말라고 권해요. 형식적인 재편(reorg)이나 선언을 기다려서 다르게 만들어 가기 시작하려 한다면, 이미 너무 늦었어요.
text_zh: 不管你是在公司里等着领导推这个事儿，还是你就是那个要推的领导，我觉得都别等了。如果你还在等什么正式的重组或者官方声明才开始换个思路做事，那就等太久了。
text_es: Ya sea que estés en una organización esperando a que tu jefe implemente esto, o seas tú el líder tratando de implementarlo, yo no esperaría. Si estás esperando una reestructuración formal o una declaración oficial para empezar a construir de manera diferente, te estás tardando demasiado.
context: In his final advice, Lenny asks what leaders should know about implementing similar AI-powered product development changes. Tomer emphasizes urgency and personal agency rather than waiting for organizational permission. He argues that individuals should start experimenting with AI tools and adopting a full-stack builder mindset immediately, regardless of whether their company has formally announced such programs. He believes waiting for official reorganizations or declarations will put people behind in the rapidly changing landscape.
vocabulary_highlights: roll this out, formal reorg

speaker: Tomer Cohen
speaker_expertise: AI/ML Products, Product Management, User Experience
text: So it wasn't like, "Oh, we have this cool technology, what can we do with it?" It was like, "Let go of what you've built. Go back to the objectives you were trying to solve and now with this technology, how can you do that objective better?"
text_ko: 그게 단순히 “우리에겐 멋진 기술이 있으니까 이걸로 뭐 해볼까?” 하는 식은 아니었어요. “지금까지 만든 것에 집착하지 말고, 원래 해결하려던 목표로 돌아가세요. 그리고 이 기술로 그 목표를 어떻게 더 잘 달성할 수 있을지부터 생각해보세요.”
text_zh: 所以不是说"哎，我们有这个酷炫的技术，能用它干点什么呢？"而是说"放下你已经做出来的东西，回到你最初想解决的问题上，现在有了这个技术，你怎么能把这个目标做得更好？"
text_es: No era como "Ay, tenemos esta tecnología súper cool, ¿qué podemos hacer con ella?" Era más bien "Suelta lo que ya construiste. Regresa a los objetivos que estabas tratando de resolver y ahora con esta tecnología, ¿cómo puedes lograr ese objetivo de manera más efectiva?"
context: Lenny asks Tomer how he helps people shift to an AI-first mindset on the ground. Tomer explains that when LinkedIn started adopting AI more broadly, they didn't begin with the technology and then look for applications. Instead, he had teams abandon their existing roadmaps and return to their core objectives, then reimagine how AI could help them achieve those goals more effectively.
vocabulary_highlights: let go of, go back to the objectives

speaker: Tomer Cohen
speaker_expertise: AI/ML Products, Product Management, User Experience
text: To really set the new purpose for it, which was this is not a springboard for other products. This is not a traffic jumpstart, it's not an upsell feed. It's really about people that matter, talking about things that I care about professionally.
text_ko: 정말로 그 서비스의 새 목적을 분명히 하자면, 다른 제품으로 이어지는 발판(springboard)이 아니에요. 트래픽을 급증시키기 위한 수단(traffic jumpstart)도 아니고, 업셀용 피드(upsell feed)도 아니에요. 핵심은 정말 중요한 사람들하고 제가 직업적으로 관심 있는 주제에 대해 이야기하는 거예요.
text_zh: 重新给它定位的话，就是说这不是为了推其他产品做跳板，也不是为了快速拉流量，更不是什么向上销售(upsell)的渠道。真正的目的就是让那些重要的人，来聊聊我在职业上真正关心的事情。
text_es: Para realmente definir el nuevo propósito, que era: esto no va a ser una plataforma de lanzamiento para otros productos. No es para generar tráfico rápido (traffic jumpstart), ni un canal para ventas adicionales (upsell feed). Realmente se trata de que gente que importa hable sobre temas que me interesan a nivel profesional.
context: Lenny asks about specific tactics that made LinkedIn's feed more engaging and social. Tomer explains how they transformed LinkedIn's feed from what was essentially an activity tracker into something more valuable. Previously, the feed served as a way to drive traffic to other LinkedIn products, but they redefined its purpose to focus purely on professional knowledge sharing between relevant people.
vocabulary_highlights: springboard, traffic jumpstart, upsell feed

speaker: Tomer Cohen
speaker_expertise: AI/ML Products, Product Management, User Experience
text: I start backwards. It's like what is the potential here? If you start from the premise that LinkedIn ultimately is a platform for economic opportunity that sits on top of a very strong social graph. Almost every aspect of economic transaction is possible.
text_ko: 저는 뒤에서부터 시작해요. 여기서 잠재력이 뭔지부터 보는 식이에요. 만약 LinkedIn이 궁극적으로 아주 강한 소셜 그래프(social graph) 위에 자리한, 경제적 기회(economic opportunity)를 제공하는 플랫폼이라고 전제하면, 거의 모든 형태의 경제적 거래(economic transaction)가 가능해요.
text_zh: 我是倒着思考的。就是说这里的潜力到底有多大？如果你从这个角度出发——领英本质上就是一个经济机会的平台，而且建立在非常强大的社交图谱(social graph)基础上。这样的话，几乎所有的经济交易都是可能的。
text_es: Yo empiezo al revés. Es como ¿cuál es el potencial real aquí? Si partes de la base de que LinkedIn al final es una plataforma de oportunidades económicas que se monta sobre una red social súper sólida. Prácticamente cualquier tipo de transacción económica es posible.
context: Lenny asks about the strategy behind LinkedIn's transformation into a platform people check frequently. Tomer describes his approach to product strategy, which involves starting with the end vision rather than current constraints. He explains LinkedIn's fundamental value proposition as connecting economic opportunities through professional relationships, which opens up massive possibilities for different types of value exchanges.
vocabulary_highlights: start backwards, sits on top of, social graph

speaker: Tomer Cohen
speaker_expertise: AI/ML Products, Product Management, User Experience
text: It's rooted in clarity and principles that ultimately lead to leadership. And the first time I got the inspiration from it was from a startup founder I met many, many years ago. Their company was on the brink of failure. They had their last attempt and they decided on a path forward and after they decided on a path forward, he was still seeing people hedging in different directions and it led into this confusion in the system where we decided people are still hedging.
text_ko: 그건 결국 리더십(leadership)으로 이어지는 명확함과 원칙에 뿌리를 두고 있어요. 그걸로부터 영감을 처음 받은 건 아주 오래전에 만난 한 스타트업 창업자였어요. 그 회사는 거의 망하기 직전이었고, 마지막 기회로 앞으로 나아갈 한 길을 정했어요. 그런데 방향을 정한 뒤에도 사람들이 여전히 여러 쪽으로 눈치 보며 주저하는, 즉 헤지(hedging)를 하는 모습이 보였고 그 때문에 조직적으로 혼란이 생겼어요.
text_zh: 这个理念源于清晰的思路和原则，最终会带来领导力。我第一次受到启发是很多很多年前遇到的一个创业者。当时他们公司快要倒闭了，就剩最后一次机会，他们确定了前进方向。但是确定方向之后，他还是看到团队里的人在观望，往不同方向摇摆，这就造成了系统性的混乱——明明已经定了方向，大家还在那里犹豫不决。
text_es: Se basa en la claridad y en principios que al final te llevan al liderazgo. Y la primera vez que me inspiré en esto fue con un fundador de startup que conocí hace muchísimos años. Su empresa estaba al borde del fracaso. Era su último intento y decidieron el rumbo a seguir, pero después de decidir el rumbo, él seguía viendo que la gente se cubría las espaldas en diferentes direcciones y esto creó una confusión en el sistema donde ya habíamos decidido, pero la gente seguía protegiéndose por si acaso.
context: Lenny asks Tomer to explain his famous phrase "We might be wrong but we're not confused." Tomer shares the origin story of this philosophy, describing how a startup founder realized that even after making a decision, team members were still pursuing different approaches. This hedging behavior created organizational confusion that prevented them from having any chance of success, even though alignment wouldn't guarantee success.
vocabulary_highlights: rooted in, on the brink of failure, hedging in different directions

speaker: Tomer Cohen
speaker_expertise: AI/ML Products, Product Management, User Experience
text: What I find people to be attached to, especially when you build an environment with a lot of alpha types is that they get attached to being right or wrong and that really creates a lot of lingering in the system, a lot of confusion and they're still stuck to their ideas. And for me, I get attached to clarity and focus.
text_ko: 제가 보기엔, 특히 알파 성향(alpha types)이 많은 환경을 만들면 사람들은 옳고 그름에 집착하게 돼요. 그게 시스템에 오래 남아 많은 혼란을 만들고 사람들이 자기 아이디어에 붙들려 있게 해요. 저는 대신 명확성(clarity)과 집중(focus)에 집착해요.
text_zh: 我发现很多人，特别是在那种聚集了很多强势型人才(alpha types)的环境里，他们就是放不下对错这个执念，这样一来整个团队就会拖泥带水的，大家都糊里糊涂的，还死抱着自己那套想法不放。但我不一样，我在乎的是把事情想明白，把注意力集中起来。
text_es: Lo que veo es que la gente se aferra mucho, especialmente cuando tienes un ambiente lleno de personalidades alfa, se aferran a tener razón o estar equivocados y eso realmente crea mucho estancamiento en el sistema, mucha confusión, y siguen pegados a sus ideas. En mi caso, yo me enfoco en la claridad y en mantener el rumbo.
context: Tomer explains the first part of his "not confused" philosophy, which focuses on clarity of thought. He describes how in organizations with many driven, competitive people (alpha types), there's often too much emphasis on being right versus being clear about direction. This attachment to being correct causes people to linger on debates and remain stuck on their original ideas rather than moving forward with a clear, unified approach.
vocabulary_highlights: alpha types, get attached to, lingering in the system, stuck to their ideas

speaker: Tomer Cohen
speaker_expertise: AI/ML Products, Product Management, User Experience
text: I love solutions that are based on first principles. That they have, there's a principle thinking about it, there's opinions about it. If you talk to folks who work with me, they'll tell you, I push a lot for what is actually your opinion, what is your potentially controversial opinion and the best principles have teeth.
text_ko: 저는 기본 원칙(first principles)을 바탕으로 한 해결책을 정말 좋아해요. 그 해결책에는 원칙이 있고, 그에 대한 의견도 있어요. 저와 함께 일하는 사람들에게 물어보면, 저는 항상 여러분의 의견, 특히 논란이 될 수 있는 의견을 많이 강조한다고 말할 거예요. 가장 좋은 원칙은 확실한 힘이 있어야 해요.
text_zh: 我特别喜欢那种基于第一性原理(first principles)的解决方案。就是说，你得有原则性的思考，得有自己的观点。跟我共事过的人都知道，我经常会追问：你真正的观点是什么？你有什么可能比较有争议的看法？最好的原则都是有锋芒的。
text_es: Me encantan las soluciones que parten de principios fundamentales (first principles). Que tengan, que haya un pensamiento de principios detrás, que haya opiniones al respecto. Si hablas con la gente que trabaja conmigo, te van a decir que siempre presiono mucho para saber cuál es realmente tu opinión, cuál es tu opinión potencialmente polémica, porque los mejores principios tienen fuerza, tienen sustancia.
context: Tomer continues explaining his approach to clarity of thought in product development. After spending time clearly defining problems, he focuses on developing solutions based on first principles - fundamental truths that guide decision-making. He emphasizes the importance of having strong, potentially controversial opinions rather than generic statements, because meaningful principles require making trade-offs that not everyone will agree with.
vocabulary_highlights: first principles, push a lot for, controversial opinion, principles have teeth

speaker: Tomer Cohen
speaker_expertise: AI/ML Products, Product Management, User Experience
text: When I reflect back on what works across my early career, it really comes down in a nutshell to this career concept of explore and exploit. You're either in a mode of explorer where you have a bunch of unknowns and you're testing to see whether or not you like it, or you're exploiting, where you actually have found something that's really rich and really deep.
text_ko: 제 초기 커리어를 되돌아보면, 결국 한마디로 요약하면 커리어 개념인 ‘탐색과 활용(explore and exploit)’이에요. 사람은 보통 두 가지 모드 중 하나에 있어요. 하나는 탐색자 모드로, 모르는 게 많아서 이게 맞는지, 좋아하는지 시험해 보는 단계고요. 다른 하나는 활용 모드로, 이미 정말 풍부하고 깊은 무언가를 찾아서 그걸 집중적으로 파고드는 단계예요.
text_zh: 回想我职业生涯早期那些成功的经验，说白了就是两个词：探索和深挖。你要么处在探索模式，面对一堆未知的东西，去试试看自己到底喜不喜欢；要么就是在深挖模式，已经找到了真正有价值、很有潜力的方向，然后全力去做。
text_es: Cuando miro hacia atrás y pienso en qué funcionó durante mis primeros años profesionales, todo se resume básicamente en este concepto de carrera: explorar y explotar. O estás en modo explorador, donde tienes un montón de incógnitas y estás probando a ver si te gusta o no, o estás explotando, donde ya encontraste algo que realmente vale la pena y tiene mucha sustancia.
context: Lenny asks Tomer for specific career advancement advice based on his rapid rise at LinkedIn. Tomer shares what he learned about his own career journey, describing a framework he calls "explore and exploit." In the exploration phase, you test different opportunities to discover what you enjoy and excel at. In the exploitation phase, you go deep into areas where you've found something valuable and meaningful to build expertise.
vocabulary_highlights: in a nutshell, mode of explorer, bunch of unknowns, really rich and really deep

speaker: Tristan de Montebello
text: The day I understood that speaking was a subconscious flow-oriented process and not a conscious process, completely changed the way I approached it. So instead of thinking tactics and frameworks and adding more to the outside of the things I need to think about, when I realized when I speak best, I'm actually not thinking about speaking.
text_ko: 말하기가 의식적인 과정(conscious process)이 아니라 무의식적이고 흐름 중심의 과정(subconscious flow-oriented process)이라는 걸 알게 된 날, 말에 대한 제 접근 방식이 완전히 달라졌어요. 그래서 전술이나 프레임워크(tactics and frameworks)를 더 생각해서 말하기에 관해 겉으로 뭔가를 더 얹으려 하기보다는, 제가 가장 잘 말할 때는 사실 말하는 것 자체를 전혀 생각하고 있지 않다는 걸 깨달았어요.
text_zh: 当我意识到说话其实是一个下意识的流动过程，而不是有意识控制的过程时，我的整个思路就彻底变了。以前我总想着各种技巧和框架(frameworks)，脑子里装一堆要考虑的东西，但后来我发现，其实我说话最好的时候，恰恰是我根本没在想着怎么说话的时候。
text_es: El día que entendí que hablar era un proceso subconsciente que fluye naturalmente y no algo consciente, me cambió completamente la forma de enfocarlo. Entonces, en lugar de estar pensando en tácticas y esquemas mentales (frameworks) y agregar más cosas en las que tengo que pensar, cuando me di cuenta de cuándo hablo mejor, en realidad no estoy pensando en el acto de hablar.
context: Lenny asks Tristan about core principles that inform his approach to teaching public speaking. Tristan explains that the biggest breakthrough in his understanding was realizing that effective speaking happens when you're in a flow state rather than consciously thinking about speaking techniques. He emphasizes that the best speakers aren't focused on the mechanics of speaking but are completely absorbed in conveying their message to the audience.
vocabulary_highlights: flow-oriented process, conscious process, tactics and frameworks

speaker: Tristan de Montebello
text: I actually think that the biggest misconception with tackling your speaking is that people grossly underestimate just how transformative it could be to your life. And the reason it's so transformative is because speaking is not a specialized skill, it's a meta skill.
text_ko: 사실 말하기 실력을 다루면서 가장 큰 오해는 사람들이 그게 자기 삶을 얼마나 크게 바꿀 수 있는지를 과소평가한다는 거예요. 그게 그렇게 큰 변화를 만드는 이유는 말하기가 특정 분야의 전문 기술이 아니라 메타 스킬 (meta skill)이기 때문이에요.
text_zh: 我觉得大家对提升演讲能力最大的误解就是，严重低估了它对你人生的改变有多大。为什么说它这么有改变力呢？因为演讲不是什么专业技能，它是一种元技能(meta skill)。
text_es: En realidad creo que el mayor error que comete la gente al trabajar en su forma de hablar es que subestiman completamente lo transformador que puede llegar a ser para su vida. Y la razón por la que es tan transformador es porque hablar no es una habilidad especializada, es una meta-habilidad (meta skill).
context: Lenny asks about the biggest misconceptions people have about becoming a better public speaker. Tristan explains that people don't realize how life-changing improving speaking skills can be. He introduces the concept that speaking is a 'meta skill' - meaning that getting better at speaking improves many other areas of your life, similar to how fitness benefits extend beyond just physical health.
vocabulary_highlights: grossly underestimate, meta skill
topics: Communication Skills, Career Development, Learning & Growth

speaker: Tristan de Montebello
text: People tend to self-sabotage a lot. I'm speaking, and obviously as I'm speaking, all of my senses are really, really heightened. So I'm aware of everything, if a word comes out a little bit weird or if it's not the word that I was expecting to hear come out of my mouth, I'm going to be very aware of that because I was expecting something and something different happens.
text_ko: 사람들은 스스로를 망치는 경우가 많아요(self-sabotage). 제가 말할 때는 당연히 모든 감각이 아주 예민해져요. 그래서 사소한 것까지 다 의식하게 돼요. 어떤 단어가 조금 이상하게 나오거나 제 입에서 나올 줄 예상했던 말과 다르면 그게 훨씬 더 신경 쓰여요, 기대했던 게 있는데 다른 일이 일어나니까요.
text_zh: 人很容易自我破坏。我在讲话的时候，很明显我所有的感官都特别敏锐。所以我能察觉到一切，如果有个词说得有点别扭，或者说出来的不是我本来想说的那个词，我马上就会意识到，因为我本来期待的是一个结果，结果出来的却是另一个。
text_es: La gente tiende a sabotearse mucho a sí misma. Cuando estoy hablando, obviamente mientras hablo, todos mis sentidos están súper alerta. Entonces me doy cuenta de todo - si una palabra sale medio rara o no es la palabra que esperaba que saliera de mi boca, me voy a dar cuenta enseguida porque estaba esperando una cosa y salió otra diferente.
context: Tristan is explaining his third tactical tip about 'staying in character' while speaking. He describes how speakers become hyper-aware of small mistakes or imperfections during their presentation. This heightened awareness often leads to self-sabotage where speakers break character by commenting on their mistakes, even though the audience typically doesn't notice these minor issues.
vocabulary_highlights: self-sabotage, heightened

speaker: Tristan de Montebello
text: If you start leaking and letting the insecurities come out, people are going to start thinking, this person doesn't really know what they're talking about. It's like a leader who isn't clear in their direction. Suddenly I'm thinking, wait, I think I have to second guess everything here because I'm not sure about this guy or this person.
text_ko: 제가 조금이라도 흔들리거나 불안한 기색이 보이면, 사람들은 '저 사람은 진짜 뭘 아는 사람이 아니구나'라고 생각하기 시작해요. 마치 방향이 분명하지 않은 리더 같아요. 그러면 갑자기 '잠깐만, 여기 있는 모든 걸 다 다시 의심해야 하나?'라고 생각하게 돼요. 이 사람을 믿을 수 있을지 확신이 없으니까요.
text_zh: 你要是开始露怯，让人看出你心里没底，别人就会想，这人其实也不太懂啊。就像一个领导自己都说不清楚方向在哪儿，我就会想，等等，这人我得打个问号，他说的每件事我都得重新考虑考虑了。
text_es: Si empiezas a mostrar tus inseguridades y se te nota la falta de confianza, la gente va a pensar "este tipo realmente no sabe de qué está hablando". Es como un líder que no tiene clara la dirección que quiere tomar. De repente empiezas a pensar "oye, espera, creo que tengo que dudar de todo lo que dice porque no le tengo confianza a esta persona".
context: Tristan continues explaining the concept of 'staying in character' by using an airplane analogy where a pilot unnecessarily worries passengers about potential problems. He explains how when speakers 'leak' their insecurities by commenting on their mistakes or expressing doubts, it forces the audience to view everything through a lens of uncertainty, similar to how unclear leadership makes people question decisions.
vocabulary_highlights: start leaking, second guess

speaker: Tristan de Montebello
text: What we're trying to do is we're trying to internalize all of these habits to the point where I don't need to consciously think about them. So it's like a gymnast who's doing their tumbling routine and jumps into the air. As they're flipping, they're not consciously trying to think of how to do a flip.
text_ko: 우리가 하려는 건 이런 습관들을 완전히 내재화(internalize)해서 제가 굳이 의식적으로 생각하지 않아도 될 정도로 만드는 거예요. 마치 체조 선수가 텀블링(tumbling) 루틴을 하다가 공중으로 뛰어올라 회전할 때처럼, 그 순간엔 '어떻게 도는 거지?'라고 의식적으로 생각하지 않잖아요.
text_zh: 我们要做的就是把这些习惯都内化，内化到什么程度呢？就是我不用刻意去想它们。就像体操运动员做翻滚动作，跳到空中的时候，在翻跟头的过程中，他们不会有意识地去想怎么翻，已经成了本能反应。
text_es: Lo que estamos tratando de hacer es interiorizar todos estos hábitos hasta el punto donde ya no tenga que pensar conscientemente en ellos. Es como un gimnasta que está haciendo su rutina de saltos y se lanza al aire. Mientras está dando vueltas, no está tratando conscientemente de pensar en cómo hacer el salto.
context: Lenny mentions his struggle with not 'leaking' his insecurities after speaking exercises, and Tristan reassures him that this self-critical voice diminishes with practice. Tristan explains that the goal is to internalize good speaking habits so they become automatic, comparing it to a gymnast who has practiced so much that complex moves become subconscious rather than requiring conscious thought.
vocabulary_highlights: internalize, tumbling routine

speaker: Tristan de Montebello
text: The old way I think is shitty. I think it's broken, and I haven't found anything out there that is innovating on this. And it drove us crazy with Michael, and that's what gave birth to the Accordion Method. What's the old way? The old way is I have a talk coming up, so I'm going to dump all of my ideas on a piece of paper or multiple pieces of paper.
text_ko: 솔직히 기존 방식은 정말 엉망이라고 생각해요. 근본적으로 문제가 있고, 이걸 혁신하는 걸 아직 본 적이 없어요. 그게 마이클과 저를 미치게 했고, 그래서 아코디언 방식(Accordion Method)이 탄생했어요. 옛 방식이 뭐냐고요? 강연이 다가오면 제 아이디어를 한 장 혹은 여러 장의 종이에 전부 적어놓는 방식이에요.
text_zh: 我觉得以前那套方法真的很烂，完全不行，而且我也没看到市面上有什么创新的做法。这个问题把我和迈克尔都快逼疯了，所以才催生了手风琴方法(Accordion Method)。那以前是怎么做的呢？就是我有个演讲要准备，然后就把脑子里所有的想法都往纸上倒，一张纸不够就用好几张纸。
text_es: La forma tradicional me parece una porquería. Está rota, y no he visto a nadie que esté innovando en esto. Nos tenía locos a Michael y a mí, y de ahí nació el Método Acordeón. ¿Cuál es la forma tradicional? Pues que tienes una presentación pendiente y te pones a volcar todas tus ideas en un papel o en varios papeles.
context: Tristan introduces the Accordion Method as an alternative to traditional speech preparation. He expresses strong criticism of the conventional approach where people write down all their ideas, rearrange them on paper, create detailed scripts, and then struggle to memorize everything. He and his co-founder Michael developed this new method because they found the traditional approach frustrating and ineffective.
vocabulary_highlights: drove us crazy, gave birth to

speaker: Tristan de Montebello
text: Switch your mindset from what I want to say to what I want people to remember and limit whatever that is you want them to remember as much as possible and that's going to give you extreme clarity.
text_ko: 내가 말하고 싶은 것에서 '사람들이 기억하길 바라는 것'으로 사고방식(mindset)을 바꿔보세요. 사람들이 기억하길 바라는 핵심을 가능한 한 단순하고 최소화하면 훨씬 더 명확해져요.
text_zh: 转变一下思路，别想着"我要说什么"，而是想"我希望别人记住什么"，然后把你想让他们记住的东西尽可能精简，这样你的思路就会特别清晰了。
text_es: Cambia tu mentalidad: en lugar de pensar en qué quieres decir, piensa en qué quieres que la gente recuerde, y limita al máximo eso que quieres que recuerden. Eso te va a dar una claridad tremenda.
context: Tristan explains the core principle behind the Bow and Arrow technique for speech preparation. He argues that most speakers focus too much on what they want to say rather than what their audience will actually remember. The Bow and Arrow method involves identifying the single most important message (the 'arrow') and supporting it with compelling content (the 'bow') to ensure maximum impact and retention.

speaker: Upasna Gautam
speaker_expertise: B2B SaaS, Product Management, User Experience
text: We hear a lot about having the skills to thrive in ambiguity in order to be a successful product manager, but to be a successful product manager in news you have to be able to thrive in chaos. And equanimity is the most important skill I've developed I think across my entire life, and it's due to all of those years of practicing mindfulness and meditation. And equanimity is one of my favorite words, it means mental calmness, composure, evenness of temper, especially in crazy, stressful situations.
text_ko: 성공적인 프로덕트 매니저(product manager)가 되려면 불확실성 속에서 잘 버티는 능력이 필요하다고들 많이 얘기해요. 그런데 뉴스업계에서는 그 정도가 아니라 혼돈 속에서도 잘 버텨내야 해요. 제 인생 전체를 통틀어 제가 길러온 가장 중요한 능력은 평정심(equanimity)이라고 생각해요. 그건 오랜 시간 마인드풀니스(mindfulness)와 명상(meditation)을 꾸준히 해온 덕분이에요. 평정심(equanimity)은 제가 특히 좋아하는 단어 중 하나예요. 뜻은 정신적 차분함, 침착함, 감정의 평정 같은 건데, 특히 정신없고 스트레스가 많은 상황에서 그런 상태를 말해요.
text_zh: 我们经常听说要想成为成功的产品经理，得有在模糊环境中游刃有余的能力，但如果你要在新闻行业做产品经理，那你必须能在一片混乱中还能干得风生水起。我觉得平常心是我这辈子培养出来最重要的能力，这都得益于我这么多年练习正念和冥想。平常心(equanimity)是我最喜欢的词之一，它指的是内心的平静、沉着，脾气稳定，特别是在那些疯狂的、压力山大的情况下。
text_es: Se habla mucho de tener las habilidades para desenvolverse bien en la ambigüedad para ser un product manager exitoso, pero para ser un product manager exitoso en medios de comunicación tienes que ser capaz de prosperar en el caos total. Y la ecuanimidad es la habilidad más importante que he desarrollado en toda mi vida, y se debe a todos esos años practicando mindfulness y meditación. La ecuanimidad es una de mis palabras favoritas, significa tranquilidad mental, compostura, mantener la calma, especialmente en situaciones locas y estresantes.
context: Lenny asks Upasna about how her meditation and mindfulness practice helps her work at CNN, which he imagines is quite hectic with breaking news. Upasna explains that working in product at a news organization requires thriving in chaos rather than just ambiguity. She introduces the concept of equanimity - mental calmness and composure in stressful situations - as the most valuable skill she's developed through years of meditation practice.
vocabulary_highlights: thrive in chaos, equanimity, evenness of temper

speaker: Upasna Gautam
speaker_expertise: B2B SaaS, Product Management, User Experience
text: It's the ability to remain un-rattled in like the highest of highs and the lowest of lows. And if you think about it in the dynamic of a workplace or human interaction, it's really the ability to pause before reacting. And reactivity is the root cause of so many of our workplace woes and product management frustrations, and when you're able to pause before reacting you can start to undo and break a lot of those negative patterns in your brain.
text_ko: 가장 기쁠 때나 가장 힘들 때에도 동요하지 않는 능력이에요. 직장 내 역학이나 사람들 사이의 상호작용을 생각해 보면, 반응하기 전에 잠깐 멈출 수 있는 능력이라고 할 수 있어요. 반응성(reactivity)은 많은 직장 내 문제들과 제품 관리(product management)에서의 불만과 답답함의 근본 원인이고, 반응하기 전에 멈출 수 있으면 마음속에 쌓인 그런 부정적인 패턴들을 풀어내고 끊어낼 수 있어요.
text_zh: 就是在最高峰和最低谷的时候都能保持淡定，不被情绪左右。你想想在职场上或者跟人打交道的时候，其实就是遇事先缓一缓，别急着反应。很多职场上的烦心事和产品管理(product management)上的糟心事，根子上都是因为反应太激烈了。如果你能做到先停一停再回应，就能慢慢打破大脑里那些负面的思维模式。
text_es: Es la capacidad de mantener la calma tanto en los momentos más altos como en los más bajos. Y si lo piensas en el contexto laboral o en las relaciones humanas, realmente es la habilidad de hacer una pausa antes de reaccionar. Y esa reactividad es la raíz de muchos de nuestros problemas en el trabajo y las frustraciones en la gestión de productos, y cuando logras pausar antes de reaccionar puedes empezar a deshacer y romper muchos de esos patrones negativos en tu mente.
context: Upasna continues explaining equanimity and its practical application in product management. She describes how equanimity helps her remain calm during extreme situations and emphasizes that the core skill is pausing before reacting. She argues that reactivity causes many workplace problems and product management frustrations, and that learning to pause can help break negative behavioral patterns.
vocabulary_highlights: remain un-rattled, highest of highs and the lowest of lows, workplace woes, undo and break

speaker: Upasna Gautam
speaker_expertise: B2B SaaS, Product Management, User Experience
text: I mean, you have to be ready to pivot at the drop of a hat. I had a big working session planned with my users to do research with them, or do user testing, and breaking news breaks, and it takes so much time and effort to gather a team of editors across the globe to do a user testing session. And when breaking news happens, they have to prioritize that over everything. So what do you do in that situation? You can be frustrated, absolutely it's frustrating. But we always have to have the ability to A, pivot of course, but also have backup and buffers in those types of scenarios.
text_ko: 그러니까, 언제든지 바로 피벗(pivot)할 준비가 돼 있어야 해요. 사용자들과 큰 워킹 세션을 열어 사용자 리서치(user research)나 사용자 테스트(user testing)를 하려고 계획했는데, 갑자기 속보(breaking news)가 터지는 경우가 있어요. 전 세계 편집자들을 모아 사용자 테스트를 하려면 시간과 노력이 엄청나게 드는데, 속보가 나면 그걸 가장 우선순위로 처리해야 하거든요. 그런 상황에서 어떻게 하겠어요? 당연히 짜증나고 답답할 수 있어요. 하지만 우리는 항상 피벗(pivot)할 수 있어야 하고, 그런 상황을 대비한 백업(backup)과 버퍼(buffers)를 갖춰놔야 해요.
text_zh: 我的意思是，你得随时准备调整方向，说变就变。我本来安排了一个大型的用户工作会议，要做用户调研和用户测试，结果突发新闻一出来，你知道要召集全球各地的编辑团队来做用户测试有多不容易吧。可一有突发新闻，他们就得把这个放在第一位，别的都得往后排。遇到这种情况你能怎么办？沮丧肯定是会沮丧的，这确实很让人头疼。但我们必须具备这种能力，第一当然是要能够快速调整方向(pivot)，第二是在这种情况下一定要有备选方案和缓冲空间。
text_es: O sea, tienes que estar listo para cambiar de estrategia en un segundo. Tenía planeada una sesión grande de trabajo con mis usuarios para hacer investigación con ellos, o hacer pruebas de usuario, y de repente salen noticias de última hora, y cuesta muchísimo tiempo y esfuerzo juntar a un equipo de editores de todo el mundo para hacer una sesión de testing de usuarios. Y cuando pasan noticias urgentes, tienen que darle prioridad a eso por encima de todo. Entonces, ¿qué haces en esa situación? Te puedes frustrar, por supuesto que es frustrante. Pero siempre tenemos que tener la capacidad de A, hacer pivot obviamente, pero también tener plan B y colchones en ese tipo de escenarios.
context: Lenny asks for a specific example of how Upasna uses her equanimity skills during chaotic moments at CNN. Upasna describes a common scenario where she has carefully planned user testing sessions with editors from around the world, but breaking news forces the journalists to abandon the session to cover the story. She explains how they build in backup plans and buffers to handle these frequent disruptions.
vocabulary_highlights: pivot at the drop of a hat, backup and buffers

speaker: Upasna Gautam
speaker_expertise: B2B SaaS, Product Management, User Experience
text: When our engineers are able to understand our journalists' needs at the same level as we are, they're able to define the how to do it with so much greater clarity and precision. And so my tech lead is embedded also in our product discovery process, he joins our user testing sessions, and our design jams, and our editorial conversation planning sessions. And he's done an amazing job of also passing that knowledge down to the rest of our engineers on our team, so it's really like this mentality of getting that important feedback from our journalists, understanding their pain points and then sharing and teaching it across the team.
text_ko: 우리 엔지니어들이 기자들의 요구를 우리만큼 잘 이해하게 되면, 어떻게 할지(how to do it)를 훨씬 더 명확하고 정확하게 정할 수 있어요. 그래서 우리 테크 리드(tech lead)는 프로덕트 디스커버리(product discovery) 과정에도 함께 들어오고, 사용자 테스트(user testing) 세션이나 디자인 잼(design jams), 편집 기획 회의(editorial planning sessions)에도 참여해요. 그리고 그는 그 지식을 팀의 다른 엔지니어들에게도 정말 잘 전수해 줬어요. 결국 기자들로부터 중요한 피드백을 받고 그들의 페인 포인트(pain points)를 이해한 뒤 팀 전체에 공유하고 가르치는 그런 마인드가 자리 잡았어요.
text_zh: 当我们的工程师能够像我们一样深入理解记者的需求时，他们就能更清晰、更精准地找到解决方案。所以我让技术负责人也参与到我们的产品发现(product discovery)流程中，他会参加用户测试，参加设计头脑风暴(design jams)，还有编辑内容规划会议。他在把这些知识传递给团队其他工程师方面做得特别好，所以现在整个团队都有这种意识——收集记者的重要反馈，了解他们的痛点，然后在团队内部分享和传授这些经验。
text_es: Cuando nuestros ingenieros logran entender las necesidades de nuestros periodistas al mismo nivel que nosotros, pueden definir el cómo hacerlo con muchísima más claridad y precisión. Entonces mi líder técnico también está metido en todo nuestro proceso de descubrimiento de producto, se une a nuestras sesiones de testing con usuarios, a nuestros design jams, y a nuestras sesiones de planificación de conversaciones editoriales. Y ha hecho un trabajo increíble pasándole ese conocimiento al resto de nuestros ingenieros del equipo, así que realmente es como esta mentalidad de recibir ese feedback tan importante de nuestros periodistas, entender sus puntos de dolor (pain points) y después compartirlo y enseñarlo a todo el equipo.
context: Lenny asks about product review meetings and decision-making processes at CNN. Upasna explains how she evolved their approach by embedding engineers directly into the product discovery process rather than keeping them separate from user research. She describes how her tech lead now participates in user testing sessions and design activities, which helps engineers better understand journalist needs and determine technical feasibility with greater precision.
vocabulary_highlights: embedded, design jams, passing that knowledge down

speaker: Upasna Gautam
speaker_expertise: B2B SaaS, Product Management, User Experience
text: In order to stay competitive in our modern news landscape, building this content management platform and the technology behind it has taught us how to enable rapid development and integration of new features and workflows. And we've been able to quickly test hypotheses while reducing risk, and again, time is of the essence when it comes to breaking news. And when you layer that with a very complex content management technology, there's a lot of moving parts. And we've been able to do that successfully, and it's pretty amazing. And because of that we've developed, I think, this unique skill of high agency under high pressure.
text_ko: 현대 뉴스 환경에서 경쟁력을 유지하려면 이 콘텐츠 관리 플랫폼(content management platform)과 그 뒤에 있는 기술(content management technology)을 구축하면서 새로운 기능과 워크플로(workflow)를 빠르게 개발하고 통합하는 법을 배웠어요. 덕분에 가설을 빠르게 검증하면서 리스크를 줄일 수 있었고, 특히 속보(breaking news)에서는 시간이 정말 중요해요. 매우 복잡한 콘텐츠 관리 기술(content management technology)이 겹치면 움직이는 부분이 많아지는데, 저희는 그걸 성공적으로 해내고 있고 솔직히 꽤 대단하다고 생각해요. 그래서 저는 고압 상황에서 높은 실행력(high agency)을 발휘하는 독특한 능력을 갖추게 된 것 같아요.
text_zh: 要想在现在这个新闻环境里保持竞争力，我们搭建这套内容管理平台(content management platform)和背后的技术，让我们学会了怎么快速开发和整合新功能、新流程(workflow)。我们能够快速验证想法的同时还降低风险，再说一遍，做突发新闻就是跟时间赛跑。再加上内容管理技术本身就很复杂，里面有很多环节要配合。我们把这些都搞定了，真的挺厉害的。正因为这样，我觉得我们练就了一个独特的本事——在高压下还能保持高执行力。
text_es: Para mantenernos competitivos en el panorama mediático actual, desarrollar esta plataforma de gestión de contenidos y toda la tecnología que hay detrás nos ha enseñado cómo facilitar el desarrollo rápido y la integración de nuevas funciones y flujos de trabajo. Y hemos podido probar hipótesis rápidamente mientras reducimos el riesgo, y como ya dije, el tiempo es crucial cuando se trata de noticias de última hora. Y cuando le sumas una tecnología de gestión de contenidos muy compleja, hay muchas piezas en movimiento. Y lo hemos logrado con éxito, y es bastante impresionante. Y gracias a eso hemos desarrollado, creo yo, esta habilidad única de tener mucha autonomía bajo mucha presión.
context: Lenny asks what skills and approaches Upasna would take to future product teams from her experience at CNN. Upasna explains how building a content management platform in the fast-paced news environment has taught her team to enable rapid development while managing complex technology with many moving parts. She emphasizes that the combination of speed requirements for breaking news and technical complexity has helped them develop what she calls 'high agency under high pressure.'
vocabulary_highlights: stay competitive, layer that with, moving parts, high agency under high pressure

speaker: Upasna Gautam
speaker_expertise: B2B SaaS, Product Management, User Experience
text: When I asked my boss why he took such a big chance on me he said, 'It's because of your communication skills and relationship-building skills, and that I've seen you in a room where engineers listen to you and what you have to say, and you listen to them.' And he was like, 'That in itself is really, really hard to teach.' And I was like, 'Okay, yeah, I can do that.' So when I think about what communication means I also attach that to mindfulness. Like mindful communication is so critical for successful product management, no matter what type of product environment you're in.
text_ko: 내가 사장님한테 왜 나한테 이렇게 큰 기회를 줬는지 물어봤을 때, 사장님이 이렇게 말씀하셨어요. '너의 커뮤니케이션 스킬과 관계 형성 능력 때문이야. 그리고 내가 너를 보았을 때, 엔지니어들이 너의 말을 듣고, 너도 그들의 이야기를 잘 들어주더라고.' 그게 정말 가르치기 힘든 부분이라고 하셨고, 나는 '아, 그럴 수 있겠구나'라고 생각했어요. 그래서 커뮤니케이션이 뭔지 생각할 때, 나는 그것을 마음 챙김(mindfulness)과 연결 지어요. 마음 챙김 커뮤니케이션은 어떤 제품 환경에서든 성공적인 제품 관리에 정말 중요하다고 생각해요.
text_zh: 我问我老板为什么敢冒这么大风险用我，他说："就是因为你的沟通能力和建立关系的能力，我看到过你在会议室里，工程师们都愿意听你说话，而你也会认真听他们的意见。"他接着说："这种能力真的很难教会别人。"我当时就想："好吧，这个我确实能做到。"所以现在我一想到沟通，就会联想到用心这个概念。用心的沟通对于成功的产品管理(product management)来说太关键了，不管你在什么样的产品环境里都是这样。
text_es: Cuando le pregunté a mi jefe por qué se arriesgó tanto conmigo, me dijo: "Es por tus habilidades de comunicación y para construir relaciones, y porque te he visto en reuniones donde los ingenieros te escuchan y prestan atención a lo que dices, y tú también los escuchas a ellos." Y me dijo: "Eso en sí mismo es súper difícil de enseñar." Y yo le dije: "Ah, sí, eso sí lo puedo hacer." Entonces cuando pienso en lo que significa la comunicación, también lo relaciono con el mindfulness. La comunicación consciente (mindful communication) es súper crítica para la gestión exitosa de productos, sin importar en qué tipo de ambiente de producto estés trabajando.
context: Lenny asks about practical tactics for dealing with unexpected events beyond meditation. Upasna shares advice her boss gave her about why he hired her for her first official product management role after a decade in tech infrastructure. She explains how her communication and relationship-building skills, particularly her ability to have engineers listen to her while also listening to them, was seen as especially valuable and difficult to teach.
vocabulary_highlights: took such a big chance on me, hard to teach, mindful communication

speaker: Uri Levine
text: So by and large I would say end of the day, we look at the global crisises and we say, "Oh, this is going to impact an industry." But as an entrepreneur, you don't care about the industry, you care about your own startup, that's it. And if the rest of the world is suffering from the same problem, doesn't help you, not even a single bit.
text_ko: 결국 정리하자면, 우리는 전 세계적인 위기(global crises)를 보며 '아, 이게 어느 업계(industry)에 영향을 주겠구나'라고 말하죠. 그런데 창업가(entrepreneur) 입장에서는 업계는 신경 안 쓰고 자기 스타트업(startup)만 신경 써요, 그게 전부예요. 그리고 세상이 다 같은 문제로 고통받는다고 해도, 그건 자기한테 아무 도움이 되지 않아요, 조금도요.
text_zh: 总的来说，我觉得最终来看，我们看到全球危机的时候会说"哦，这会影响整个行业"。但作为创业者，你根本不在乎什么行业，你只在乎你自己的初创公司(startup)，就这么简单。全世界其他人都遇到同样的问题，对你一点用都没有，一丁点儿帮助都没有。
text_es: En general, yo diría que al final del día, vemos las crisis globales y decimos "Ay, esto va a impactar toda la industria." Pero como emprendedor, te vale madre la industria - perdón por la expresión - te importa tu propia startup y ya. Y si el resto del mundo está sufriendo el mismo problema, no te ayuda para nada, ni tantito.
context: Lenny asks Uri about how global crises like COVID affected startups, using Uri's restaurant reservation platform Order.chat as an example. Uri explains that while many companies failed during COVID, entrepreneurs shouldn't take comfort in industry-wide problems. He emphasizes that founders must focus solely on their own company's survival rather than finding solace in the fact that competitors are also struggling.
vocabulary_highlights: by and large, not even a single bit

speaker: Uri Levine
text: So two types of, abstractly, two types of crisis. One is that I would call that a cash crisis. So all of a sudden your cash program or plan is being jeopardized, for losing a customer, disappearing investor, not meeting your expectation, dramatic price change in the market and so forth. And the other one is lose of product market fit.
text_ko: 추상적으로 보면 위기는 크게 두 가지예요. 하나는 제가 '자금 위기(cash crisis)'라고 부르는 건데, 예를 들어 갑자기 고객을 잃거나 투자자가 떠나거나 기대에 못 미치거나 시장에서 가격이 급격히 변해서 현금 흐름이나 자금 운영 계획이 위태로워지는 상황이에요. 다른 하나는 제품-시장 적합성(product-market fit)을 잃는 거예요.
text_zh: 抽象来说，有两种危机。一种我叫它现金危机，就是突然间你的现金流计划出了问题，可能是丢了大客户、投资人跑了、业绩没达到预期，或者市场价格大幅波动什么的。另一种就是产品和市场不匹配了，失去了product market fit。
text_es: Entonces hay dos tipos de crisis, hablando en abstracto. Una que yo llamaría crisis de liquidez o de caja. De repente tu programa de flujo de efectivo o tu plan se ve amenazado, ya sea por perder un cliente importante, que desaparezca un inversionista, no cumplir tus expectativas, un cambio drástico de precios en el mercado, y cosas así. Y la otra es la pérdida del product market fit.
context: Lenny asks Uri to create a taxonomy of the different types of crises that founders face. Uri breaks down the major existential threats into two categories: cash crises (when your funding or revenue streams are suddenly at risk) and product-market fit crises (when your product becomes irrelevant). He explains that cash crises involve financial pressures like losing customers or investors, while product-market fit loss means you need to start over completely.
vocabulary_highlights: abstractly, all of a sudden, being jeopardized, and so forth

speaker: Uri Levine
text: Never give up is the most important behavior of successful CEOs of startup. The second one, by the way, is making decisions with conviction. If you don't make them with conviction, then the team is not going to follow. If the team is not going to follow, then you are not going to be successful.
text_ko: 성공한 스타트업(startup)의 최고경영자(CEO)들에게 가장 중요한 행동은 절대 포기하지 않는 거예요. 두 번째로 중요한 건 확신(conviction)을 가지고 결정을 내리는 거예요. 확신 없이 결정을 하면 팀이 따라오지 않고, 팀이 따라오지 않으면 결국 성공하기 어렵거든요.
text_zh: 对于创业公司的CEO来说，永不放弃是成功最重要的品质。第二个呢，就是要有魄力地做决策。如果你做决定的时候犹犹豫豫的，团队就不会跟着你走。团队都不跟你，那你肯定做不成事儿。
text_es: Nunca rendirse es lo más importante que tienen que hacer los CEOs exitosos de startups. Lo segundo, por cierto, es tomar decisiones con convicción. Si no las tomas con convicción, entonces el equipo no te va a seguir. Y si el equipo no te sigue, no vas a tener éxito.
context: Lenny asks Uri about his advice to never give up during a crisis. Uri explains the two most critical behaviors for startup CEOs: persistence and decisive leadership. He emphasizes that making decisions with conviction is essential because team members need to see strong leadership to maintain their commitment, especially during difficult times when uncertainty could cause talented people to leave the company.
vocabulary_highlights: making decisions with conviction

speaker: Uri Levine
text: At the end of the day, you cannot rely on someone else, you have only one company, you need to make sure that this company is successful. When you assume responsibility, you're basically saying, "You know what, I control my own destiny."
text_ko: 결국 다른 사람한테 기대할 수는 없어요. 여러분에겐 단 하나의 회사뿐이니 그 회사를 성공시키는 건 여러분의 몫이에요. 책임을 진다는 건 사실상 "있잖아요, 내 운명은 내가 결정해요"라고 말하는 거예요.
text_zh: 说到底，你不能指望别人，你就这么一家公司，必须确保它能成功。当你承担起责任的时候，其实就是在说："我的命运我做主。"
text_es: Al final del día, no puedes depender de otra persona, solo tienes una empresa, y tienes que asegurarte de que esa empresa sea exitosa. Cuando asumes la responsabilidad, básicamente estás diciendo: "¿Sabes qué? Yo controlo mi propio destino."
context: Lenny discusses Uri's philosophy that founders must take complete responsibility for their company's success or failure, even when external factors are involved. Uri explains why founders shouldn't blame market conditions or other external circumstances for their failures. He argues that taking full responsibility empowers founders to believe they can control their outcomes and increases their likelihood of success.
vocabulary_highlights: at the end of the day, control my own destiny

speaker: Uri Levine
text: The longer that you wait, you actually lose options. The only ability to choose is today. This is one of the most challenging part of a crisis. You actually need to make a decision rapidly, like today.
text_ko: 더 오래 기다릴수록 선택권이 줄어들어요. 선택할 수 있는 건 오늘뿐이에요. 위기에서는 이게 가장 어려운 부분 중 하나예요. 실제로는 오늘처럼 빠르게 결정을 내려야 해요.
text_zh: 你拖得越久，选择就越少。能做决定的机会就是现在。这就是危机最难的地方——你必须快速做决定，就是今天。
text_es: Mientras más tiempo esperes, en realidad vas perdiendo opciones. La única oportunidad real de elegir es hoy. Esta es una de las partes más difíciles de una crisis. Necesitas tomar la decisión rápido, como que ya.
context: Lenny asks about the importance of acting quickly during a crisis. Uri is explaining why founders must make difficult decisions immediately when facing a cash crisis. Using a mathematical example of runway extension, he demonstrates how delaying cost-cutting decisions by even a few months can eliminate the founder's ability to extend their runway to the desired length, making speed of decision-making critical for startup survival.
vocabulary_highlights: lose options, rapidly

speaker: Uri Levine
text: If you are in the middle of it and you ask yourself, so what are the chances that we will end up being successful? It looks way smaller. Way smaller. So what happened here is that you realize that, okay, this is not forever, so ski is going to come back but we don't know how long and therefore we assume that it's going to be for two seasons until it's coming back, until 2022.
text_ko: 그 상황 한가운데에 있을 때 스스로 '우리가 결국 성공할 가능성은 얼마나 될까?' 하고 물어보면, 가능성은 훨씬 작아 보여요. 훨씬 작아요. 그래서 여기서 벌어진 일은 '아, 이건 영원히 계속되는 게 아니구나'라고 깨닫게 된다는 거예요. 스키는 다시 돌아오겠지만 언제일지는 모르니까 다시 돌아올 때까지 두 시즌 정도, 그러니까 2022년까지 계속될 거라고 가정하게 되는 거예요.
text_zh: 当你身处其中的时候，你会问自己，我们成功的几率到底有多大？看起来真的很渺茫，非常渺茫。所以这时候你就意识到，好吧，这种情况不会永远持续下去，滑雪产业肯定会回来的，但我们不知道要多久，所以我们假设可能要两个雪季才能恢复，也就是要到2022年。
text_es: Si estás en pleno proceso y te preguntas, ¿cuáles son las posibilidades de que al final tengamos éxito? Se ve mucho más difícil. Muchísimo más difícil. Entonces lo que pasó aquí es que te das cuenta de que, bueno, esto no es para siempre, el esquí va a regresar pero no sabemos cuándo y por eso asumimos que va a ser por dos temporadas hasta que regrese, hasta 2022.
context: Uri is describing how his ski vacation booking company WeSki survived the COVID crisis. When the pandemic shut down European ski resorts, the company faced potential bankruptcy since they were supposed to become profitable that year. Uri explains how the team had to make assumptions about how long the crisis would last and plan accordingly, even though success seemed unlikely when they were in the thick of the crisis.
vocabulary_highlights: way smaller, in the middle of it, end up being successful

speaker: Uri Levine
text: During crisis, people will appreciate more than anything else transparency. And if you hide information from them, then they would leave, they don't trust you anymore. But if there is a crisis, and look, if there is a crisis then everyone knows that there is a crisis, it's not surprising for anyone.
text_ko: 위기 상황에서는 무엇보다 투명성(transparency)을 가장 높게 평가해요. 정보를 숨기면 사람들은 떠나고 더 이상 신뢰하지 않아요. 어차피 위기가 닥치면 모두가 그 사실을 알고 있어서 누구에게도 놀랄 일이 아니에요.
text_zh: 遇到危机的时候，大家最看重的就是透明度。你要是藏着掖着不告诉他们实情，人家就会走人，再也不信任你了。但是如果真的出了危机，你想想，既然出了危机，那大家肯定都知道有问题，这也不是什么意外的事儿。
text_es: Durante una crisis, la gente va a valorar más que nada la transparencia. Y si les ocultas información, entonces se van a ir, ya no confían en ti. Pero si hay una crisis, y mira, si hay una crisis entonces todo el mundo sabe que hay una crisis, no es ninguna sorpresa para nadie.
context: Lenny asks Uri for advice on keeping team members motivated and engaged during a crisis. Uri emphasizes the critical importance of transparent communication with employees during difficult times. He explains that hiding bad news from the team will backfire because people can sense when something is wrong, and dishonesty will cause them to lose trust and leave the company when you need them most.
vocabulary_highlights: more than anything else, it's not surprising for anyone

speaker: Uri Levine
text: Fall in love, fall in love, fall in love, fall in love with the problem, and then actually what you're trying to do is engage everyone else to fall in love with the same problem, to go into this journey, into this path and follow your leadership there.
text_ko: 그 문제에 푹 빠져보세요, 진짜로요. 그리고 사실 여러분이 하려는 건 다른 사람들까지 같은 문제에 빠지게 해서 함께 이 여정을 떠나 같은 길을 걷고 여러분의 리더십을 따르게 만드는 거예요.
text_zh: 要爱上这个问题，真的要爱上它，然后你要做的就是让其他人也爱上同一个问题，跟着你一起走这条路，认你这个领头人。
text_es: Enamórate, enamórate completamente del problema, y entonces lo que realmente tienes que hacer es lograr que todos los demás también se enamoren de ese mismo problema, que se metan en este viaje, en este camino y que sigan tu liderazgo.
context: Lenny introduces Uri by highlighting his impressive track record of co-founding 10 companies and building two unicorns including Waze. He notes that the biggest startup lesson Uri seems to have taken from all this experience is to fall in love with the problem. Uri explains that this passionate connection to a problem is essential not just personally, but also for inspiring others - your team, customers, and stakeholders - to join you on the entrepreneurial journey.
vocabulary_highlights: engage everyone else, go into this journey, follow your leadership

speaker: Uri Levine
text: Every time that you hire someone new, mark your calendars for 30 days down the road and ask yourself one question, knowing what I know today, would I hire this person? If the answer is no, fire them immediately.
text_ko: 사람을 새로 채용할 때마다 30일 뒤 날짜를 달력에 표시해 두고 스스로에게 한 가지 질문을 해 보세요: "지금 제가 아는 걸 바탕으로 이 사람을 다시 채용하겠어요?" 만약 답이 "아니요"라면 즉시 해고하세요.
text_zh: 每次招新人的时候，在日历上标记一下30天后的日期，然后问自己一个问题：基于我现在了解到的情况，我还会招这个人吗？如果答案是不会，那就立马开掉他们。
text_es: Cada vez que contrates a alguien nuevo, márcate en el calendario 30 días después y hazte una sola pregunta: con lo que sé hoy, ¿volvería a contratar a esta persona? Si la respuesta es no, córrela inmediatamente.
context: Lenny asks Uri about his advice on hiring and firing. Uri shares a very specific tactical approach for managing new hires effectively. He emphasizes that many startup failures stem from founders knowing within the first month that team members aren't the right fit, but failing to act on that knowledge. His solution is to create a systematic 30-day checkpoint to force this difficult but crucial decision.
vocabulary_highlights: mark your calendars, down the road

speaker: Uri Levine
text: Most people are missing the most important slide of their presentation is the first slide. This slide is going to be presented for the longest period of time. This is the place that you're going to put your strongest point. Now the second most important slide is the last one.
text_ko: 대부분의 사람들은 발표에서 가장 중요한 슬라이드를 놓치는데, 바로 첫 슬라이드예요. 첫 슬라이드는 청중에게 가장 오래 보이는 슬라이드라서 가장 강한 핵심을 여기에 담아야 해요. 그리고 두 번째로 중요한 건 마지막 슬라이드예요.
text_zh: 很多人都忽略了一个问题，就是演示文稿里最重要的其实是第一张PPT。这张PPT展示的时间是最长的，所以你得把最有说服力的观点放在这里。然后呢，第二重要的就是最后一张PPT了。
text_es: La mayoría de la gente no se da cuenta de que la diapositiva más importante de su presentación es la primera. Esta diapositiva es la que van a ver por más tiempo. Aquí es donde tienes que poner tu punto más fuerte. Y la segunda diapositiva más importante es la última.
context: Lenny transitions the conversation to fundraising advice. Uri shares a tactical insight about presentation structure that most entrepreneurs overlook. He explains that the first slide (usually just a title slide) and the last slide (usually just 'thank you') are displayed for the longest periods during a pitch meeting, yet founders typically waste these prime real estate moments instead of using them strategically to reinforce their strongest points.
vocabulary_highlights: prime real estate, reinforce

speaker: Uri Levine
text: So when you fall in love with the problem, then what happened is that the problem is going to serve as the North Star of your journey, and when you have a North Star, you're going to make less deviation from the course and you are way more likely to become successful. But also the story that you are about to tell is way more compelling.
text_ko: 문제 자체에 푹 빠지면, 그 문제가 당신 여정의 북극성(North Star)이 돼요. 북극성이 있으면 방향을 잃을 일이 줄고 목표에서 벗어나는 일이 적어져 성공할 가능성이 훨씬 커져요. 게다가 전하려는 이야기 자체도 훨씬 더 설득력 있고 매력적이에요.
text_zh: 所以当你真正爱上这个问题的时候，这个问题就会成为你前进路上的北极星(North Star)，有了北极星，你就不会偏离方向，成功的概率也会大大提高。而且你要讲的故事也会更有说服力。
text_es: Entonces cuando te enamoras del problema, lo que pasa es que ese problema se va a convertir en tu estrella polar en este camino, y cuando tienes una estrella polar, te vas a desviar mucho menos del rumbo y tienes muchas más probabilidades de tener éxito. Pero además, la historia que vas a contar va a ser mucho más convincente.
context: Lenny asks Uri about whether there was a specific moment he realized that falling in love with the problem was the key insight, or if it developed progressively. Uri explains that this concept evolved over time as he recognized that entrepreneurship is fundamentally about value creation, and solving problems is the simplest way to create value. He describes how focusing on the problem provides strategic and storytelling advantages.
vocabulary_highlights: serve as the North Star, deviation from the course, way more compelling

speaker: Uri Levine
text: If you start your story with, 'Our company is,' or, 'Our system is,' and in the recent year everything is, 'Our AI system is,' or, 'Our AI company is.' But generally speaking, if you start your story with that, you focus on your solution. If you start with the story with, 'The problem we are solving is,' Then you focus on the problem. If your story start with, 'The value that we create for you is,' then you focus on the user. The last two are way better than focus on the solution.
text_ko: 이야기를 '우리 회사는...'이나 '우리 시스템(system)은...'으로 시작하면, 요즘은 '우리 AI(Artificial Intelligence) 시스템은...'이나 '우리 AI(Artificial Intelligence) 회사는...'처럼 시작하는 경우가 많아요. 그런데 그렇게 말하면 솔루션(solution)에만 초점을 맞추게 돼요. 반면에 '우리가 해결하려는 문제는...'으로 시작하면 문제에 초점을 맞추고, '우리가 여러분에게 제공하는 가치는...'으로 시작하면 사용자(user)에 초점을 맞추게 돼요. 뒤의 두 가지가 솔루션 중심으로 말하는 것보다 훨씬 좋아요.
text_zh: 如果你一开口就说"我们公司是..."或者"我们的系统是..."，最近这一年大家都在说"我们的AI系统是..."或者"我们的AI公司是..."。但是说白了，你要是这样开头的话，你关注的就是你的解决方案。如果你换个说法，"我们要解决的问题是..."，那你关注的就是问题本身。要是你说"我们为您创造的价值是..."，那你关注的就是用户。后面这两种说法比只关注解决方案要好得多。
text_es: Si empiezas tu historia con "Nuestra empresa es" o "Nuestro sistema es", y últimamente todo es "Nuestro sistema de IA es" o "Nuestra empresa de IA es"... Pero en general, si arrancas tu historia así, te estás enfocando en tu solución. Si empiezas la historia con "El problema que resolvemos es", entonces te enfocas en el problema. Si tu historia empieza con "El valor que creamos para ti es", entonces te enfocas en el usuario. Estas últimas dos opciones son muchísimo mejores que enfocarse en la solución.
context: Uri continues explaining why falling in love with the problem is crucial for entrepreneurs. He points out that he receives many emails from entrepreneurs weekly, and they all start by describing what they're building rather than why they're building it. He breaks down different ways to frame your startup story and explains why focusing on the problem or user value is more effective than focusing on your solution or technology.
vocabulary_highlights: generally speaking, way better than

speaker: Uri Levine
text: So if you speak with a hundred people, but if you actually speak with 20 people that you don't know, you will get validated whether or not this problem is real or not. And look, it's not the only way to become successful, right? You look at one of the most successful products in the world, the iPhone, right? And you ask yourself, what was exactly the problem when they started? And the answer is that there was no problem when they started.
text_ko: 그러니까 100명하고 얘기한다고 해도, 실제로 모르는 사람 20명하고만 얘기해 보면 그 문제가 진짜인지 아닌지 확인할 수 있어요. 그리고 이게 성공하는 유일한 방법은 아니에요. 예를 들어 전 세계에서 가장 성공한 제품 중 하나인 아이폰(iPhone)을 보면, 그들이 시작할 때 정확히 어떤 문제가 있었냐고 물어보면 답은 시작할 때는 문제가 없었다는 거예요.
text_zh: 所以你要是跟一百个人聊过，但实际上只要跟20个你不认识的人好好聊聊，你就能验证出这个问题到底是不是真的存在。但话说回来，这也不是成功的唯一路子，对吧？你看世界上最成功的产品之一——iPhone，你问问自己，他们刚开始做的时候到底要解决什么问题？答案是，他们开始的时候根本就没有什么问题要解决。
text_es: Entonces, si hablas con cien personas, pero realmente hablas con 20 personas que no conoces, vas a poder validar si este problema es real o no. Y mira, no es la única manera de triunfar, ¿verdad? Si te fijas en uno de los productos más exitosos del mundo, el iPhone, ¿no? Te preguntas, ¿cuál era exactamente el problema cuando empezaron? Y la respuesta es que no había ningún problema cuando empezaron.
context: Lenny asks Uri for signals and heuristics to help founders understand if a problem is big enough to warrant building a company around it. Uri explains his '100 people' validation approach, emphasizing that you need to get out of your comfort zone and talk to strangers, not just friends and family. He acknowledges that problem-solving isn't the only path to success, using the iPhone as an example of a revolutionary product that didn't solve an existing problem but created entirely new value.
vocabulary_highlights: get validated, get out of your comfort zone

speaker: Uri Levine
text: The biggest enemy of good enough is perfect. You don't need to be perfect. You need to be good enough in order to win the market, and the way that you are going to become good enough, by the way, is really simple. You start with not good enough and you iterate and iterate and iterate until you become good enough and then you'll win.
text_ko: 완벽이 '충분히 좋은(good enough)'의 가장 큰 적이에요. 완벽할 필요는 없어요. 시장에서 이기려면 충분히 좋은 수준이면 돼요. 그리고 그 수준에 도달하는 방법은 사실 아주 단순해요. 처음엔 충분히 좋지 않은 상태로 시작해서 반복(iterate)해서 계속 개선하다 보면 결국 충분히 좋아져서 이기게 돼요.
text_zh: 做到"够好"的最大敌人就是追求完美。你不需要做到完美，只需要够好就能赢得市场。而且说实话，达到够好的方法特别简单——你从不够好开始，然后不断迭代(iterate)，一遍遍地改进，直到变得够好，这样你就赢了。
text_es: El mayor enemigo de "lo suficientemente bueno" es la perfección. No necesitas ser perfecto. Lo que necesitas es ser lo suficientemente bueno para ganar el mercado, y la forma de llegar a ser lo suficientemente bueno, por cierto, es muy sencilla. Empiezas con algo que no está lo suficientemente bueno y vas iterando y iterando y iterando hasta que te vuelves lo suficientemente bueno, y entonces vas a ganar.
context: Uri is explaining the multi-dimensional nature of the startup journey, particularly focusing on how it's a journey of failures where founders must try different approaches until something works. He emphasizes the importance of failing fast to allow more attempts at success. In this quote, he's addressing the perfectionism that often paralyzes entrepreneurs, explaining that the path to success is through iterative improvement rather than trying to build something perfect from the start.
vocabulary_highlights: good enough, win the market, iterate and iterate

speaker: Varun Mohan
speaker_expertise: AI/ML Products, Sales Strategy, Growth Strategy
text: I think one of the things that's maybe a little bit undervalued is this kind of agency piece. And I think about this a lot, which is, you have a lot of people that could go through college and go through school and they're basically told exactly what to do on a P-set. They're given these very, very, I would say, well-defined paths that they need to take. I think maybe in society and just school, we don't prioritize how do you make sure you get people with real agency that want to build something, right?
text_ko: 조금 과소평가되는 것 중 하나가 이런 자기 주도성(agency) 측면인 것 같아요. 이걸 많이 생각하는데, 대학이나 학교를 다니면서 P-set(문제 풀이 과제)에서 뭘 해야 할지 정확히 지시받는 사람이 많아요. 그들에게는 따라야 할 아주 딱 정해진 길만 주어지죠. 사회나 학교에서는 뭔가를 만들고 싶어하는 진짜 자기 주도성(agency)을 가진 사람들을 어떻게 키울지 우선순위로 두지 않는 것 같아요.
text_zh: 我觉得有一个东西可能被低估了，就是这种主动性。我经常想这个问题，就是很多人上大学的时候，做作业都是老师告诉你怎么做，给你安排得明明白白的路径。我觉得可能在社会上，包括在学校里，我们都没有重视怎么培养那些真正有主动性、想要去创造点什么的人，对吧？
text_es: Creo que algo que tal vez no valoramos lo suficiente es este tema de la autonomía personal. Y pienso mucho en esto: tienes un montón de gente que puede pasar por la universidad, por toda su educación, y básicamente les dicen exactamente qué tienen que hacer en cada tarea. Les dan estos caminos súper, súper definidos, diría yo, que tienen que seguir. Creo que tal vez en la sociedad y en la educación no priorizamos cómo asegurarnos de formar gente con verdadera autonomía que realmente quiera construir algo, ¿no?
context: Lenny asks Varun what skills people should be investing in more with the rise of AI building more and more of our products. Varun explains that beyond technical skills like understanding computer systems and problem-solving, the most undervalued skill is agency - the ability to take initiative and build things independently rather than just following well-defined instructions. He contrasts this with traditional education where students are told exactly what to do, arguing that society doesn't prioritize developing people who have real agency and want to create something meaningful.
vocabulary_highlights: a little bit undervalued, agency piece, well-defined paths, real agency

speaker: Varun Mohan
speaker_expertise: AI/ML Products, Sales Strategy, Growth Strategy
text: I want the company to almost be like this dehydrated entity. Every hire is like a little bit of water, and we only go back and hire someone when we're back to being dehydrated.
text_ko: 회사를 거의 탈수된 존재(dehydrated entity)처럼 유지하고 싶어요. 채용은 사람 한 명 한 명이 물 한 방울 같은 거라서, 다시 탈수 상태가 됐을 때만 사람을 뽑아요.
text_zh: 我希望公司就像一个脱水的生物体一样。每招一个人就像加了一点水，只有当我们又"脱水"了，才会再去招人。
text_es: Quiero que la empresa sea casi como una entidad deshidratada. Cada contratación es como un poquito de agua, y solo volvemos a contratar a alguien cuando ya estamos deshidratados otra vez.
context: Lenny asks Varun how he knows when it's time to hire someone at Codeium. Varun explains his hiring philosophy using a metaphor - he wants the company to operate lean like a dehydrated entity, where each new hire is like adding water. They only hire when teams are truly underwater and desperately need help, not when they have adequate resources. This prevents the politics and manufactured work that happens when companies hire before they actually need people.
vocabulary_highlights: dehydrated entity, go back and hire, back to being dehydrated

speaker: Varun Mohan
speaker_expertise: AI/ML Products, Sales Strategy, Growth Strategy
text: A lot of the bets we're making inside the company are for things that are not three, four weeks away. We should be cannibalizing the existing state of our product every six to 12 months. Every six to 12 months, it should make our existing product look silly. It should almost make the form factor of existing product look dumb.
text_ko: 우리가 회사 안에서 하는 많은 베팅(bets)은 3~4주 안에 끝나는 일이 아니에요. 6~12개월마다 기존 제품을 카니발라이징(cannibalizing)할 수 있어야 해요. 매번 6~12개월마다 새로 나온 게 기존 제품을 우스꽝스럽게 만들고, 기존 제품의 폼팩터(form factor)가 어리숙해 보일 정도여야 해요.
text_zh: 我们公司内部下的很多赌注都不是三四个礼拜就能见效的。我们应该每隔六到十二个月就颠覆一下现有产品。每隔六到十二个月，就要让我们现在的产品看起来很傻，甚至让现有产品的外形设计看起来都很蠢。
text_es: Muchas de las apuestas que estamos haciendo dentro de la empresa son para cosas que no van a pasar en tres o cuatro semanas. Deberíamos estar canibalizando el estado actual de nuestro producto cada seis o doce meses. Cada seis o doce meses, debería hacer que nuestro producto actual se vea ridículo. Casi debería hacer que el factor de forma (form factor) del producto existente se vea súper tonto.
context: Varun discusses what he considers the most counterintuitive aspect of building AI products. While users and the market focus on short-term weekly improvements, internally Codeium is making longer-term bets that aren't visible for months. He explains their philosophy of continuously disrupting their own product - every 6-12 months they should be building something that makes their current offering look outdated and obsolete in both functionality and design.
vocabulary_highlights: cannibalizing, form factor, look dumb

speaker: Varun Mohan
speaker_expertise: AI/ML Products, Sales Strategy, Growth Strategy
text: The engineers are now able to produce more technology. The ROI of building technology has actually gone up. This actually means you hire more. The best thing to do is just get your hands dirty with all of these products. You could be a force multiplier to your organization in ways in which they never even anticipated.
text_ko: 엔지니어들이 이제 더 많은 기술을 만들어낼 수 있어요. 기술을 만드는 것에 대한 투자수익률(ROI)이 실제로 올라갔고, 이건 결국 더 많이 채용해야 한다는 뜻이에요. 가장 좋은 방법은 이런 제품들을 직접 뛰어들어 써보고 손으로 다뤄보는 거예요. 그렇게 하면 당신은 조직에서 그들이 전혀 예상하지 못한 방식으로 영향력을 배가시키는 존재(force multiplier)가 될 수 있어요.
text_zh: 现在工程师们能开发出更多技术了。搞技术的投资回报率(ROI)其实是在上升的。这其实意味着你得多招人。最好的办法就是亲自上手去试试这些产品。你可能会成为组织里的力量倍增器(force multiplier)，发挥出他们想都想不到的作用。
text_es: Los ingenieros ahora pueden desarrollar más tecnología. El ROI de crear tecnología en realidad ha subido. Esto significa que vas a contratar más gente. Lo mejor que puedes hacer es meterte de lleno con todos estos productos. Podrías ser un multiplicador de fuerza (force multiplier) para tu organización de maneras que ni siquiera se imaginaban.
context: Lenny asks about skills people should invest in with AI building more products. Varun argues against the common belief that AI will reduce demand for engineers. Instead, he explains that AI tools make engineers more productive, increasing the return on investment of building technology. This higher ROI actually justifies hiring more engineers, not fewer. He encourages people to get hands-on experience with AI tools because they can become force multipliers in their organizations in unexpected ways.
vocabulary_highlights: ROI of building technology, get your hands dirty, force multiplier

speaker: Varun Mohan
speaker_expertise: AI/ML Products, Sales Strategy, Growth Strategy
text: I think one of the worst things is like, if someone comes here and doesn't like using these tools, we believe there are massive productivity improvements. We do bring people into the company on site so we can actually see how they think through problems on a whiteboard and all these other pieces. So we do want to see how they think on their feet and hopefully they're not just taking what we're saying, putting it in a voice translator and sticking it into ChatGPT and getting the answer out.
text_ko: 제가 생각하기에 제일 안 좋은 상황 중 하나는, 누군가가 여기 와서 이런 도구 쓰는 걸 싫어하는 거예요. 우리는 이런 도구들이 생산성을 엄청 끌어올린다고 보고 있어요. 그래서 사람들을 실제로 사무실(온사이트 on-site)로 불러 화이트보드 앞에서 문제를 어떻게 풀어가는지 같은 과정을 직접 보려고 해요. 즉석에서 어떻게 생각하는지 보길 원하고, 단지 우리가 말한 걸 음성 번역기(voice translator)에 넣어서 ChatGPT에 붙여 넣고 답만 뽑아내는 식이 아니길 바래요.
text_zh: 我觉得最糟糕的情况就是，如果有人来了之后不愿意用这些工具，我们是真心相信这些工具能大幅提升工作效率的。我们会把人请到公司现场，这样就能实实在在地看到他们怎么在白板上思考问题，还有其他各种表现。所以我们确实想看看他们的临场反应能力，希望他们不只是把我们说的话丢进语音翻译器，然后再扔给ChatGPT来找答案。
text_es: Creo que una de las peores cosas es cuando alguien llega aquí y no le gusta usar estas herramientas, porque nosotros creemos que hay mejoras enormes de productividad. Por eso traemos a la gente a la empresa en persona para poder ver realmente cómo razonan los problemas en la pizarra y todo eso. Queremos ver cómo piensan sobre la marcha y ojalá que no estén simplemente tomando lo que decimos, metiéndolo en un traductor de voz y pegándolo en ChatGPT para sacar la respuesta.
context: Lenny asks how Codeium conducts interviews in an era where AI tools like Windsurf can solve coding problems. Varun explains their approach to modern technical interviews - they actually encourage candidates to use AI tools during interviews because they believe in the productivity improvements these tools provide. However, they also conduct on-site interviews with whiteboarding to assess real-time problem-solving abilities and ensure candidates aren't just mechanically translating problems into AI prompts without genuine understanding.
vocabulary_highlights: think on their feet, voice translator, sticking it into

speaker: Varun Mohan
speaker_expertise: AI/ML Products, Sales Strategy, Growth Strategy
text: I think maybe in society and just school, we don't prioritize how do you make sure you get people with real agency that want to build something, right? Their goal is not just to maybe graduate from college and then get a job at a big tech company where they're told exactly what to do or where to put the pixel for this one website. I think that's maybe a skill set that is undervalued just right now, probably in the last maybe 10 years or so.
text_ko: 저는 사회나 학교에서 진짜로 뭔가를 만들고 싶어 하는 사람들의 주체성(agency)을 어떻게 확보할지 우선순위로 두지 않는 것 같아요. 그들의 목표가 단지 대학을 졸업해서 빅테크(big tech) 회사에 들어가 거기서 시키는 대로만 하는 것—예를 들어 어떤 웹사이트의 픽셀(pixel)을 어디에 놓으라고 지시받는 일—이 아니잖아요. 이런 스킬셋(skill set)이 요즘, 아마 지난 10년 정도 동안 특히 저평가돼 온 것 같아요.
text_zh: 我觉得可能在社会上，包括学校里，我们都没有重视一个问题：怎么培养那些真正有主动性、想要创造点什么的人才，对吧？他们的目标不应该只是从大学毕业，然后去大厂找个工作，每天被人安排得死死的，就负责在某个网页上调调像素位置什么的。我觉得这种能力可能被低估了，特别是最近这十年左右。
text_es: Creo que tal vez en la sociedad y en las escuelas no le damos prioridad a cómo asegurarnos de formar gente con verdadera iniciativa que quiera construir algo, ¿no? Su objetivo no es solo graduarse de la universidad y luego conseguir trabajo en una empresa tecnológica grande donde les digan exactamente qué hacer o dónde poner cada pixel en una página web. Pienso que esa habilidad está subvalorada justo ahora, probablemente en los últimos diez años más o menos.
context: Varun continues explaining why agency is an undervalued skill in the AI era. He critiques how society and educational systems don't prioritize developing people with genuine agency who want to create meaningful things. Instead, many people follow a predictable path of graduating college and joining large tech companies where they're given very specific, narrow tasks like positioning pixels on websites. He argues this lack of agency has been undervalued for about a decade and will become increasingly important.
vocabulary_highlights: real agency, where to put the pixel, skill set that is undervalued

speaker: Varun Parmar
text: Every single day, every single time somebody is pushing your code to production and you're releasing a feature or an enhancement, you are making the product better or you're making the product worse, but the products never remain same. So with every release that your competitor is making and every release that you're making, you are either making chess points, moves against them, positive points, or you're going negative.
text_ko: 매일매일, 누군가 당신의 코드를 프로덕션에 배포(deploy)해서 기능(feature)이나 개선사항(enhancement)을 릴리스(release)할 때마다, 제품은 좋아지거나 나빠질 뿐 같은 상태로 남아 있지 않아요. 경쟁사가 내는 릴리스(release) 하나하나와 당신이 내는 릴리스 하나하나가 쌓여서, 상대에게 한 수 앞서는 건지(체스의 수, chess move) 아니면 뒤처지는 건지, 긍정적인 점수를 얻는 건지 아니면 잃는 건지를 결정해요.
text_zh: 每天都有人把代码推到生产环境(production)，每次发布新功能或者优化的时候，你要么是在让产品变得更好，要么就是在让它变差，反正产品肯定不会原地踏步。所以你的竞争对手每发一个版本，你每发一个版本，其实就像下棋一样，要么你走了好棋占了上风，要么就是走坏了让自己处于劣势。
text_es: Cada día, cada vez que alguien sube código a producción y lanzas una funcionalidad nueva o una mejora, estás haciendo que tu producto sea mejor o lo estás empeorando, pero nunca se queda igual. Entonces, con cada lanzamiento que hace tu competencia y cada lanzamiento que haces tú, estás ganando puntos a favor, haciendo jugadas estratégicas contra ellos, o te estás quedando atrás.
context: Lenny asks Varun about his core product philosophies and how competition impacts product strategy. Varun explains his belief that products are never static - they're always improving or declining relative to competitors. He uses a chess metaphor to describe how every product release by you or your competitors creates relative gains or losses in the market. This framework helps product teams understand the competitive impact of their work and drives clarity around prioritization decisions.
vocabulary_highlights: chess points, moves against them, going negative

speaker: Varun Parmar
text: The success of a company is a direct relation of what the competition allows you to do. Every single instance when I looked at a company accelerated their growth or there was a deceleration of growth, it was a direct relation to what the competition allowed you to do.
text_ko: 회사의 성공은 경쟁이 허용하는 것과 직접적으로 연관돼요. 제가 본 모든 사례에서 어떤 회사의 성장이 가속화되거나 둔화된 건 전부 경쟁이 허용해 준 것과 직결됐어요.
text_zh: 一家公司能不能成功，说白了就看竞争对手给你留多少空间。我每次分析那些增长很快或者突然放缓的公司，发现都是一个道理——竞争对手让你做什么，你就只能做什么。
text_es: El éxito de una empresa tiene que ver directamente con lo que te permite hacer la competencia. Cada vez que he visto que una empresa aceleró su crecimiento o se le frenó, siempre fue por lo que la competencia le dejó hacer o no hacer.
context: Lenny discusses how Miro continues to succeed despite intense competition in the collaborative whiteboarding space. Varun shares one of his core philosophies about business growth - that a company's success is fundamentally constrained or enabled by competitive dynamics. He argues that while companies must execute well internally, the competitive landscape is often the biggest variable determining whether growth accelerates or decelerates.
vocabulary_highlights: direct relation, deceleration of growth, direct relation to

speaker: Varun Parmar
text: What you want to do is that you want to be the first one to hit the brick wall. If you consider yourself as an innovation-centric company and you believe that you are building experiences that fundamentally don't exist anywhere else and you're sort of paving the way for the rest of the folks to basically get inspired with how you are building these experiences, speed is the single biggest determinant.
text_ko: 하고 싶은 건 먼저 한계에 부딪히는 사람이 되는 거예요. 스스로를 혁신 중심(innovation-centric) 회사라고 생각하고, 다른 곳엔 전혀 없는 근본적인 경험을 만들고 있다고 믿으며, 그 방식으로 업계의 다른 사람들에게 영감을 주고 있다면, 결국 가장 중요한 건 속도(speed)이에요.
text_zh: 你要做的就是第一个撞墙的人。如果你把自己定位成一家以创新为核心的公司，相信自己在打造的体验是其他地方根本没有的，而且你在为其他人铺路，让他们从你打造的这些体验中获得灵感，那速度就是最关键的决定因素。
text_es: Lo que quieres hacer es ser el primero en toparse con la pared. Si te consideras una empresa centrada en la innovación y crees que estás creando experiencias que básicamente no existen en ningún otro lugar, y que de alguna manera estás abriendo el camino para que el resto se inspire en cómo estás construyendo estas experiencias, entonces la velocidad es el factor más determinante.
