context: Lenny asks about Varun's product philosophies and how to balance moving fast versus moving carefully. Varun explains his belief that innovative companies should prioritize speed to discover learning faster than competitors. The 'hitting the brick wall first' metaphor means being the first to encounter and learn from failures, allowing you to course-correct while competitors are still pursuing the wrong path. This philosophy emphasizes speed as crucial for innovation leadership.
vocabulary_highlights: hit the brick wall, innovation-centric, paving the way, single biggest determinant

speaker: Varun Parmar
text: My fundamental belief here, Lenny, is that every product manager actually wants to move fast. I think the reason why in some cases we are not able to move fast is because of roadblocks that we run into and those roadblocks can manifest themselves into technical challenges, they can manifest them in cells of organizational challenges, they could be priority challenges.
text_ko: 레니, 제 기본적인 믿음은 모든 프로덕트 매니저(product manager)들이 사실 더 빨리 움직이고 싶어한다는 거예요. 어떤 경우에 우리가 빨리 움직이지 못하는 이유는 부딪히는 장애물들(roadblocks) 때문이라고 생각해요. 그런 장애물들은 기술적인 문제(technical challenges)로 나타날 수도 있고, 조직적인 문제(organizational challenges)의 형태로 드러날 수도 있으며, 우선순위 문제(priority challenges)일 수도 있어요.
text_zh: 伦尼，我的基本看法是这样的，其实每个产品经理都想快速推进项目。我觉得有时候我们推不快的原因，主要是遇到了各种阻碍，这些阻碍可能表现为技术难题，也可能是组织架构上的问题，或者是优先级不清楚的问题。
text_es: Mi convicción fundamental aquí, Lenny, es que todo product manager en realidad quiere avanzar rápido. Creo que la razón por la que a veces no logramos avanzar rápido es por los obstáculos que nos encontramos, y esos obstáculos pueden presentarse como desafíos técnicos, pueden manifestarse como problemas organizacionales, o pueden ser temas de prioridades.
context: Lenny asks how to help teams move faster beyond just telling them to 'move faster.' Varun explains his philosophy that product managers are naturally driven by challenge and want to move quickly - it's their inherent personality type. He argues that slowness isn't due to lack of motivation but rather systemic roadblocks that need to be identified and removed. His approach focuses on enabling PMs to raise issues quickly so leadership can unblock them.
vocabulary_highlights: manifest themselves into, cells of organizational challenges

speaker: Varun Parmar
text: We have a motto in the product org, it's very simple, single sentence, deliver customer value faster with high quality. Everything that we do, and when I say everything, everything, Lenny, from performance and reward system and measurements, everything is based on this one single statement.
text_ko: 우리 제품 조직(product org)에는 모토가 하나 있어요. 아주 단순한 한 문장인데요: '고품질로 고객 가치를 더 빠르게 전달하자' — 우리가 하는 모든 일, 정말 말 그대로 모든 것, Lenny, 성과와 보상 시스템(performance and reward system)부터 측정(measurements)까지 전부 이 한 문장에 기반해 있어요.
text_zh: 我们产品团队有个座右铭，特别简单，就一句话：更快地为客户创造高质量的价值。我们做的所有事情，我说的是所有事情啊，Lenny，从绩效到奖励制度到各种考核指标，全都是围绕这一句话来的。
text_es: Tenemos un lema en el equipo de producto, es muy sencillo, una sola frase: entregar valor al cliente más rápido y con alta calidad. Todo lo que hacemos, y cuando digo todo, es TODO, Lenny, desde el sistema de rendimiento y recompensas hasta las métricas, absolutamente todo se basa en esta única declaración.
context: Lenny asks about how Miro operationalizes their philosophy of moving fast and removing blockers. Varun explains Miro's core product organization motto that guides all their decisions and systems. The motto has three components: delivering customer value (measured by actual usage and metrics), moving faster (tracked through cycle times), and maintaining high quality (evaluated through design reviews). This simple statement drives their performance reviews, measurements, and organizational culture.

speaker: Varun Parmar
text: You have two personas that you have to think about. The fundamental thing that you have to do is drive accountability. When you put on the persona hat of a stream leader, your number one goal that you have, is drive improvement. When you go sit in the product leadership team, your number one goal is actually to drive accountability around this.
text_ko: 생각해야 할 페르소나(persona)가 두 가지 있어요. 근본적으로 해야 할 일은 책임(accountability)을 확실히 하는 거예요. 스트림 리더(stream leader) 역할일 때는 최우선 목표가 개선을 추진하는 거고, 제품 리더십 팀(product leadership team)에 있을 때는 실제로 가장 중요한 건 이 부분에 대한 책임(accountability)을 분명히 하는 거예요.
text_zh: 你得考虑两个不同的角色。最根本的是，你必须推动问责制(accountability)。当你戴上流程负责人(stream leader)这顶帽子的时候，你的首要目标就是推动改进。但当你坐在产品领导团队里的时候，你的首要目标其实是围绕这个来推动问责制(accountability)。
text_es: Tienes que pensar en dos roles diferentes. Lo fundamental que tienes que hacer es impulsar la rendición de cuentas (accountability). Cuando te pones el sombrero de líder de flujo (stream leader), tu objetivo número uno es impulsar la mejora. Cuando te sientas en el equipo de liderazgo de producto, tu objetivo número uno es realmente impulsar la rendición de cuentas alrededor de esto.
context: Lenny asks about Varun's philosophy for developing product leaders at Miro. Varun explains his framework where product leaders must balance two distinct roles or 'personas.' As stream leaders, they focus on continuously improving their team's performance and outcomes. As members of the product leadership team, they must hold each other accountable for company-wide decisions and performance. This dual responsibility ensures both individual team success and collective leadership effectiveness.
vocabulary_highlights: persona hat, drive accountability, drive improvement

speaker: Vijay Iyengar
text: One of the things after you've been in engineering for a while is that develop this tendency to immediately respond with no to new ideas. And I think from the engineering perspective, this is because you spend a lot of your time building and maintaining ideas that maybe are half thought out or didn't really go anywhere, and you just feel like the full brunt of the maintenance cost of that. And so you build up the scar tissue and this immune response to say no to new ideas, and it's a hard no, like no, we're definitely not going to do it.
text_ko: 한동안 엔지니어링(engineering)을 하다 보면 새로운 아이디어에 바로 '안 돼'라고 반응하는 버릇이 생겨요. 엔지니어 관점에서는 그 이유가 아마도 대부분의 시간을 반쯤 생각만 해보고 끝나 버리거나 실제로는 잘 진행되지 않았던 아이디어들을 만들고 유지하는 데 쓰기 때문이에요. 그런 아이디어들의 유지 비용(maintenance cost)을 온전히 떠안는 느낌이 들고요. 그래서 흉터 조직(scar tissue)처럼 쌓인 경험이 면역 반응(immune response)을 만들면서, 새로운 아이디어에 대해 '아니야, 절대 안 해' 하는 식의 완전한 거부(hard no)를 하게 돼요.
text_zh: 搞技术搞久了，你就会发现自己有个毛病，一听到新想法就条件反射地说"不行"。我觉得从工程师的角度来看，这是因为你花了太多时间去搭建和维护那些想得不够成熟或者根本没啥前途的项目，维护成本(maintenance cost)全都压在你身上。时间长了你就有了心理阴影，形成了一种免疫反应(immune response)，一听到新想法就说不，而且是坚决不干的那种不。
text_es: Una de las cosas que pasa después de que llevas un tiempo en ingeniería es que desarrollas esta tendencia de responder inmediatamente que no a las ideas nuevas. Y creo que desde la perspectiva de la ingeniería, esto es porque pasas mucho tiempo construyendo y manteniendo ideas que tal vez están medio pensadas o que realmente no van a ningún lado, y sientes todo el peso del costo de mantenimiento de eso. Entonces te vas blindando y desarrollas como una respuesta inmune de decir que no a las ideas nuevas, y es un no rotundo, o sea no, definitivamente no lo vamos a hacer.
context: Lenny asks Vijay what he had to unlearn as an engineer when transitioning to product leadership. Vijay explains how engineers develop a defensive mindset against new ideas because they experience the ongoing maintenance burden of poorly thought-out features. This creates what he calls 'scar tissue' - a protective response that makes engineers reflexively reject new proposals with a 'hard no' to avoid future problems.
vocabulary_highlights: full brunt, scar tissue, immune response, hard no

speaker: Vijay Iyengar
text: The issue for us at the time was that we took people away from the investment in our core product to go do those other things. We moved people, right? And so the trap there is that you leave yourself ripe for disruption in your core because someone else can out invest you in that core. And so if you are the leader in some core product, our takeaway here is you should continue to out invest everyone else in that core and then invest the profits that come out of that core into the next venture.
text_ko: 그때 우리의 문제는 핵심 제품(core product)에 대한 투자를 줄이고 사람들을 다른 일로 옮겼다는 점이었어요. 사람들을 옮겼죠? 그래서 생기는 함정은 누군가가 그 핵심에 우리보다 더 많이 투자(out-invest)하면 핵심 영역에서 스스로 교란(disruption)에 취약해진다는 거예요. 그래서 어떤 핵심 제품에서 리더(leader)라면, 결론은 그 핵심에 대해 계속 누구보다 더 많이 투자(out-invest)하고, 그 핵심에서 나오는 수익은 다음 벤처(next venture)에 재투자해야 한다는 것입니다.
text_zh: 我们当时的问题就是，把原本投入在核心产品上的人力都调去做别的事情了，对吧？这样做的风险就是，你的核心业务很容易被别人颠覆，因为竞争对手可能在这块投入比你更多。所以说，如果你在某个核心产品上是老大，我们的经验就是，你必须在这个核心业务上的投入要超过所有竞争对手，然后用核心业务赚来的钱去投资下一个项目。
text_es: El problema que tuvimos en ese momento fue que sacamos gente de la inversión en nuestro producto principal para ponerlos a hacer esas otras cosas. Movimos personal, ¿no? Y ahí está la trampa: te quedas vulnerable a que te interrumpan (disrupt) en tu área central porque alguien más puede invertir más que tú en esa área. Entonces, si eres el líder en algún producto central, lo que aprendimos es que tienes que seguir invirtiendo más que todos los demás en esa área principal, y luego usar las ganancias que salen de ahí para invertir en el siguiente proyecto.
context: Lenny asks about Mixpanel's journey of expanding to multiple products and then refocusing back to their core analytics product. Vijay explains the strategic mistake they made - they moved engineering resources away from their core product to build adjacent products, which made them vulnerable to competitors who could outinvest them in analytics. His key insight is that market leaders should maintain their investment advantage in their core product while funding new ventures with profits, not people.
vocabulary_highlights: ripe for disruption, out invest, takeaway

speaker: Vijay Iyengar
text: But one of the traps with RICE that we observed is that the C and E, the confidence and effort tends to cause you to prematurely deprioritize potentially high reach, high impact bets, really innovative things. And we encountered this on one of our teams early last year were we just RICE'd everything, all the ideas, and a lot of the high reach, high impact things ended up at the bottom because confidence and effort were just so murky for them, as they should be typically for high reach, high impact ideas.
text_ko: 근데 RICE(Reach, Impact, Confidence, Effort)를 쓰면서 우리가 관찰한 함정 하나는 C(Confidence, 확신)랑 E(Effort, 노력) 때문에 잠재적으로 리치(reach)도 크고 임팩트(impact)도 큰, 정말 혁신적인 베팅들을 너무 일찍 우선순위에서 밀어내게 만든다는 거예요. 작년 초에 한 팀에서 실제로 그걸 겪었어요. 그 팀은 모든 아이디어를 RICE로만 점수화했는데, 리치가 크고 임팩트가 큰 아이디어들이 많이 아래로 내려갔어요. 그런 아이디어들은 보통 확신이나 노력이 불투명한 경우가 많은데(그게 당연하죠), 그래서 우선순위가 낮아진 거예요.
text_zh: 但是我们发现RICE有个坑，就是那个C和E，信心度(confidence)和工作量(effort)这两项，容易让你过早地把那些潜在的高覆盖、高影响力的想法给排到后面去，就是那些真正有创新性的东西。去年年初我们有个团队就遇到过这种情况，把所有想法都用RICE打了分，结果那些高覆盖、高影响力的项目全跑到最底下去了，因为信心度和工作量这两项对它们来说就是很模糊的，其实对于高覆盖、高影响力的想法来说，本来就应该是这样的。
text_es: Pero una de las trampas que vimos con RICE es que la C y la E, o sea la confianza y el esfuerzo, tienden a hacerte que despriorities muy rápido apuestas que podrían tener mucho alcance y alto impacto, cosas realmente innovadoras. Y nos pasó esto con uno de nuestros equipos a principios del año pasado donde le aplicamos RICE a todo, a todas las ideas, y muchas de las cosas de alto alcance y alto impacto terminaron hasta abajo porque la confianza y el esfuerzo estaban súper confusos para esas ideas, como normalmente debería ser para ideas de alto alcance y alto impacto.
context: Lenny asks about prioritization frameworks and Vijay's approach to helping product teams prioritize effectively. Vijay discusses the RICE framework (Reach, Impact, Confidence, Effort) and explains a common pitfall - the Confidence and Effort components often cause teams to unfairly penalize innovative, high-impact ideas because these factors are inherently unclear for breakthrough concepts. He describes how his team experienced this when they applied RICE and all the most innovative ideas scored poorly.
vocabulary_highlights: prematurely deprioritize, high reach, high impact bets, RICE'd everything, murky

speaker: Vijay Iyengar
text: One approach that I found really interesting is from this book called Shape Up by Basecamp, which this idea of appetite over estimates, where instead of making the estimate an output of planning, you make the time box or an appetite the input, and you say, 'We want to solve X problem and we're willing to invest six weeks solving that problem.'
text_ko: 제가 정말 흥미롭게 본 접근법 중 하나는 Basecamp(베이스캠프)의 책 'Shape Up(Shape Up)'에 나오는, '추정(estimate)보다 투자 의향(appetite)을 우선하는(appetite over estimates)'이라는 아이디어예요. 즉 계획의 산출물로 추정을 만드는 대신 타임박스(timebox)나 어피타이트(appetite) 같은 시간·투자 한도를 입력값으로 잡고, "우리는 X 문제를 해결하려고 하고 그걸 해결하는 데 6주를 투자하겠다"라고 정하는 방식이에요.
text_zh: 我觉得Basecamp那本《Shape Up》里有个思路特别有意思，就是用appetite来替代estimates，不是先做规划再估时间，而是反过来，先定个时间框或者说appetite作为输入条件，然后说"我们要解决X问题，愿意投入六周时间来搞定这个问题。"
text_es: Una estrategia que me pareció súper interesante es de este libro que se llama Shape Up de Basecamp, con esta idea del apetito (appetite) por encima de las estimaciones, donde en lugar de que la estimación sea el resultado de la planificación, haces que el tiempo disponible o el apetito (appetite) sea lo que determines desde el principio, y dices: 'Queremos resolver el problema X y estamos dispuestos a invertir seis semanas en resolver ese problema.'
context: Lenny and Vijay are discussing estimation challenges in product development. Vijay explains the core problem with traditional estimation - teams are asked to estimate before they fully understand what they're building. He introduces the 'appetite over estimates' concept from Basecamp's Shape Up methodology, where instead of estimating how long something will take, you decide upfront how much time you're willing to invest in solving a particular problem.
vocabulary_highlights: appetite over estimates, time box, appetite the input

speaker: Vijay Iyengar
text: And one of the rituals that it's enabled is we'll find that engineers will go into that channel and react with a message with an email emoji, which means I'm going to email this customer and find out more, right? And they'll just email the customer and say, 'Hey, I'm the engineer that built this feature. I saw you said this specific thing. Can you tell me more? I'd love to understand.' They ask the five why's, and then they improve the product on their own.
text_ko: 그리고 그로 인해 생긴 습관 중 하나는 엔지니어들이 그 채널(channel)에 들어가 이메일 이모지(email emoji)로 반응하는 모습을 보는 거예요. 그건 '내가 이 고객에게 이메일을 보내서 더 알아볼게요'라는 뜻이에요. 실제로 그들은 고객에게 이메일을 보내서 "안녕하세요, 이 기능을 만든 엔지니어입니다. 말씀하신 이 부분을 봤는데, 좀 더 자세히 얘기해주실 수 있나요? 더 이해하고 싶어요."라고 보내요. 파이브 와이즈(5 Whys)를 묻고, 그 과정에서 스스로 제품을 개선해요.
text_zh: 这样就形成了一个习惯，我们发现工程师会在那个频道里看到用户反馈，然后用邮件的表情符号回应，意思就是"我要给这个客户发邮件了解一下情况"。然后他们就直接给客户写邮件说："嗨，我就是开发这个功能的工程师，我看到你提到了这个具体问题，能跟我详细说说吗？我特别想了解一下。" 他们会问五个为什么(five whys)，然后主动去优化产品。
text_es: Y uno de los hábitos que esto ha creado es que vemos que los ingenieros entran a ese canal y reaccionan a un mensaje con el emoji del email, que significa "voy a escribirle a este cliente para averiguar más", ¿sí? Y simplemente le mandan un correo al cliente diciéndole: "Hola, soy el ingeniero que desarrolló esta función. Vi que dijiste esto específico. ¿Me puedes contar más? Me encantaría entender mejor." Hacen los cinco porqués (five whys) y luego mejoran el producto por su cuenta.
context: Lenny asks about Mixpanel's unique approach to keeping product teams close to customers. Vijay explains how they created an automated Slack feed of customer feedback that all engineers and designers can access directly. He describes a ritual that emerged where engineers use emoji reactions to signal they'll reach out to customers directly, then email them to dig deeper into problems using techniques like the 'five whys' to understand root causes and improve the product independently.
vocabulary_highlights: rituals that it's enabled, react with a message, five why's
topics: Product Management, Communication Skills, Learning & Growth

speaker: Vijay Iyengar
text: I think the biggest mistake is setting up analytics using client side SDKs, client side tracking. So, web and mobile SDKs, putting a mixpanel.track or segment.track in your web app or your mobile apps. And reason it's a hot take is that for many people that's product analytics and SDK tracking are synonymous. They're like, 'All right, Mixpanel means SDK, I have to put an SDK in my web and mobile app. But that's a mistake because it... We've just seen time and time again, it leads to poor data quality and difficulty to maintain that data.
text_ko: 제가 보기엔 가장 큰 실수는 애널리틱스를 클라이언트 쪽 SDK(client-side SDKs)나 클라이언트 측 트래킹(client-side tracking)으로 구축하는 거예요. 예를 들어 웹·모바일용 SDK(web and mobile SDKs)를 넣고 웹 앱이나 모바일 앱에 mixpanel.track이나 segment.track 같은 트래킹 코드를 심는 식이죠. 이게 핫테이크(hot take)인 이유는 많은 사람들이 제품 애널리틱스(product analytics)랑 SDK 트래킹을 동일시하기 때문이에요. 'Mixpanel이면 SDK다, 웹·모바일 앱에 SDK를 넣어야 해'라고 생각하는 건데, 그건 실수예요. 반복해서 보면 그렇게 하면 데이터 품질이 떨어지고 그 데이터를 유지·관리하기도 훨씬 어려워지거든요.
text_zh: 我觉得最大的错误就是用客户端SDK来做数据分析，也就是客户端追踪。比如在网页和移动端SDK里面加个mixpanel.track或者segment.track到你的web应用或者手机app里。我说这个观点比较激进，是因为很多人觉得产品分析(product analytics)和SDK追踪就是一回事儿。他们想的是，"好吧，Mixpanel就意味着SDK，我必须在我的网页和手机应用里装个SDK。" 但这其实是个误区，因为我们一次又一次地看到，这样做会导致数据质量很差，而且后期维护这些数据特别麻烦。
text_es: Creo que el error más grande es configurar la analítica usando SDKs del lado del cliente, o sea, tracking del lado del cliente. Me refiero a SDKs web y móviles, poniendo un mixpanel.track o segment.track en tu aplicación web o en tus apps móviles. Y la razón por la que esto es controversial es que para mucha gente la analítica de producto y el tracking por SDK son la misma cosa. Piensan: "Bueno, Mixpanel significa SDK, tengo que meter un SDK en mi app web y móvil." Pero eso es un error porque... Lo hemos visto una y otra vez, termina dando una calidad de datos pésima y hace súper difícil mantener esos datos.
context: Lenny asks Vijay what most people get wrong when setting up product analytics, given his expertise as head of product at Mixpanel. Vijay shares what he calls a 'hot take' - that using client-side SDKs for tracking is a major mistake. He explains that many people assume product analytics requires putting tracking code directly in web and mobile apps, but this approach consistently leads to poor data quality and maintenance challenges, contradicting common industry practice.
vocabulary_highlights: hot take, SDK tracking are synonymous, time and time again

speaker: Vikrama Dhiman
text: When I was younger and I was starting off, I used to think it's all about the product. If you've got a really cool product to work on, your growth's guaranteed. And if you got really a product which no one cares about or a stream which no one cares about, then your growth is going to be slightly slower. But as I started seeing more and more product managers at their craft, I saw that working on a cool product area is not the only thing.
text_ko: 젊었을 때, 커리어 초반엔 모든 게 프로덕트(product) 문제라고 생각했어요. 진짜 멋진 프로덕트를 다루고 있으면 성장(growth)은 보장된다고 믿었죠. 반대로 아무도 관심 없는 제품이나 사업 분야라면 성장 속도가 더딜 거라고도 생각했고요. 그런데 여러 훌륭한 프로덕트 매니저(product manager)들을 직접 보면서, 멋진 제품 분야에서 일하는 것만이 전부는 아니라는 걸 알게 됐어요.
text_zh: 我刚入行的时候比较年轻，总觉得产品就是一切。你要是做的产品特别酷，增长肯定没问题。要是做个没人关心的产品或者没人在意的业务线，那增长肯定会慢一些。但后来接触了越来越多厉害的产品经理，看他们怎么做事，我才发现光是做酷炫的产品并不是全部。
text_es: Cuando era más joven y estaba empezando, pensaba que todo se trataba del producto. Si tienes un producto realmente genial en el que trabajar, tu crecimiento está garantizado. Y si tienes un producto que a nadie le importa o un área que a nadie le interesa, entonces tu crecimiento va a ser más lento. Pero conforme empecé a ver a más y más product managers en acción, me di cuenta de que trabajar en un área de producto genial no es lo único que importa.
context: Lenny asks Vikrama about the common traits of product managers who have had rapid career growth. Vikrama explains how his understanding of career success evolved from his early career misconception. He initially believed that working on exciting, high-impact products would automatically guarantee career advancement, while working on less visible products would slow growth. However, through observing many product managers over his decade and a half of experience, he discovered this assumption was flawed.
vocabulary_highlights: starting off, stream which no one cares about, at their craft

speaker: Vikrama Dhiman
text: I created a career growth framework for product managers, which comprises of three things, and I call it three W's. So what you produce, what you bring to the table, and what's your operating model? The really strong product managers are good at usually two of the three things. The ones who rise and when they are rising, they are performing well on all the three access.
text_ko: 저는 프로덕트 매니저(product managers)를 위한 경력 성장 프레임워크(career growth framework)를 만들었어요. 세 가지 요소로 구성돼 있어서 저는 이를 '세 가지 W(three W's)'라고 부릅니다. 즉, 무엇을 만들어 내는지(what you produce), 어떤 가치를 제공하는지(what you bring to the table), 그리고 어떤 식으로 일하는지, 다시 말해 운영 모델(operating model)은 어떤지요. 진짜 강한 프로덕트 매니저들은 보통 이 세 가지 중 두 가지에 강해요. 반면에 실제로 성장하거나 승진하는 사람들은 세 가지 모두에서 잘해요.
text_zh: 我为产品经理做了一个职业发展框架，主要包括三个方面，我叫它"三个W"。就是你能产出什么，你能带来什么价值，还有你的工作方式是怎样的。真正厉害的产品经理通常在这三个方面能做好其中两个。而那些往上升的，正在上升期的产品经理，这三个维度他们都表现得很不错。
text_es: Creé un marco de desarrollo profesional para product managers que tiene tres componentes, y lo llamo "las tres W" (three W's). O sea: qué produces, qué aportas al equipo, y cuál es tu modelo operativo. Los product managers realmente sólidos por lo general dominan dos de estas tres áreas. Los que ascienden y están en pleno crecimiento son los que rinden bien en las tres dimensiones.
context: After observing that product success doesn't guarantee career growth, Vikrama created his framework to explain what actually drives PM career advancement. The three W's framework identifies the core areas where product managers need to excel: outputs/deliverables, their unique contributions and skills, and how they collaborate with others. He notes that good PMs typically excel in two areas, but those experiencing rapid career growth perform well across all three dimensions.
vocabulary_highlights: comprises of, bring to the table, operating model
topics: Career Development, Product Management, Strategy & Planning

speaker: Vikrama Dhiman
text: The mistake that I see a lot of product managers make is they start operating in either output or outcomes. And when you are transitioning to outcomes, it's very important that you continue to still hone your craft on outputs. For instance, do you just give up on the go-to-market strategy or do you start making product nodes which are then picked up by marketing people and are able to be used to create that go-to-market strategy?
text_ko: 제가 자주 보는 실수는 많은 프로덕트 매니저들이 일을 아웃풋(output)이나 아웃컴(outcome) 중 한쪽에만 치우쳐서 시작한다는 거예요. 아웃컴(outcome)으로 전환할 때에도 아웃풋(output)에 대한 역량을 계속 갈고닦는 게 정말 중요해요. 예를 들어, 그냥 고투마켓 전략(go-to-market strategy)을 포기해 버리나요, 아니면 마케팅 담당자들이 가져가서 실제로 그 고투마켓 전략을 만드는 데 쓸 수 있는 프로덕트 노드(product nodes)를 만들기 시작하나요?
text_zh: 我发现很多产品经理都会犯一个错误，就是要么只关注产出(output)，要么只关注结果(outcomes)。当你开始向结果导向转型的时候，继续打磨你在产出方面的能力还是很重要的。比如说，你是直接放弃市场推广策略不管了，还是说你会做一些产品要点(product nodes)，然后市场部的人可以拿去用来制定推广策略？
text_es: El error que veo mucho en los product managers es que empiezan a trabajar solo en outputs o solo en outcomes. Y cuando estás haciendo la transición hacia outcomes, es súper importante que sigas puliendo tu técnica en outputs. Por ejemplo, ¿vas a abandonar completamente la estrategia de go-to-market o empiezas a crear product nodes que después el equipo de marketing pueda usar para armar esa estrategia de go-to-market?
context: Vikrama is explaining the first W of his framework - 'what you produce' - which progresses from outputs to outcomes to strategic direction. He warns against a common pitfall where PMs abandon execution skills as they advance in their careers. Even senior PMs should maintain their ability to create detailed, actionable deliverables rather than only focusing on high-level strategy and goals.
vocabulary_highlights: hone your craft, product nodes, picked up by
topics: Product Management, Career Development, Leadership & Management

speaker: Vikrama Dhiman
text: You must have that impact through the artifacts that you work on. For a lot of product managers, when I ask, 'Hey, I was working on this very impactful area. I'm not able to have the impact on my career, what is missing?' And when I go and ask, 'Can you show me your last PRD? Can you show me the last product note that you sent? Can you show me the product strategy doc that you have or collaborated on? Can you show me the brief that you sent to the design team on the problems and the ranking of those problems?' Usually, you'll find something or the other missing.
text_ko: 여러분이 만든 산출물(artifacts)을 통해 그 영향력을 보여줘야 해요. 많은 프로덕트 매니저(product managers)들에게 제가 "저는 굉장히 영향력 있는 일을 했는데 그게 경력으로 이어지지 않아요. 뭐가 부족한가요?"라고 물어보면, 제가 "마지막 제품 요구사항 문서(PRD)를 보여줄 수 있어요? 마지막으로 보낸 제품 노트(product note)는요? 직접 작성했거나 함께 작업한 제품 전략 문서(product strategy doc)는요? 디자인팀에 보낸 문제와 그 우선순위를 정리한 브리프(brief)는요?"라고 물어보곤 해요. 보통 뭔가 하나쯤은 빠져 있더라고요.
text_zh: 你必须通过你做的这些具体产出来体现影响力。很多产品经理跟我说，"我在做一个很有影响力的项目，但对我职业发展没什么帮助，到底缺了什么？" 然后我就问他们，"你能给我看看你最近的PRD吗？你发的产品总结能看一下吗？你写的或者参与的产品策略文档在哪里？你给设计团队的需求说明，包括问题优先级排序，能给我看看吗？" 通常情况下，你总会发现这里面缺了点什么。
text_es: Tienes que lograr ese impacto a través de los entregables en los que trabajas. Con muchos product managers, cuando les pregunto: "Oye, estaba trabajando en un área muy impactante, pero no logro tener el impacto que quiero en mi carrera, ¿qué me está faltando?" Y cuando voy y les digo: "¿Me puedes enseñar tu último PRD? ¿Me puedes mostrar la última nota de producto que mandaste? ¿Me puedes enseñar el documento de estrategia de producto que tienes o en el que colaboraste? ¿Me puedes mostrar el brief que le mandaste al equipo de diseño sobre los problemas y la priorización de esos problemas?" Por lo general, vas a encontrar que algo les está faltando.
context: Lenny asks about the second W - 'what you bring to the table.' Vikrama explains this means demonstrating your unique impact through tangible work products and documents. When PMs struggle with career growth despite working on successful products, he investigates their actual deliverables like PRDs, strategy docs, and design briefs. Often these artifacts are missing or poor quality, which prevents them from showing their individual contribution to the product's success.
vocabulary_highlights: impact through the artifacts, something or the other missing

speaker: Vikrama Dhiman
text: There are three tenets that I define in working well as a product manager with others. Number one is raise difficult issues without being difficult to work with. Bring out important topics without drawing importance to yourself. And finally, you are in charge of getting the decisions made and not making all the decisions yourself.
text_ko: 다른 사람들과 잘 협업하는 제품 관리자(product manager)가 되기 위해 제가 정한 세 가지 원칙이 있어요. 첫째, 함께 일하기 어렵게 굴지 않으면서도 어려운 이슈는 제기해요. 둘째, 자신을 내세우지 않으면서도 중요한 사안은 꺼내요. 마지막으로, 결정을 내리게 하는 책임은 본인이 지되 모든 결정을 혼자 내리지는 않아요.
text_zh: 我觉得做好产品经理，跟别人配合好，有三个要点。第一个就是该提的难题必须提，但别让人觉得你这个人很难搞。第二个是要把重要的事情摆到台面上来讨论，但不要老想着突出自己。最后一个，你的职责是推动大家把决策做出来，而不是什么决定都你一个人说了算。
text_es: Hay tres principios que defino para trabajar bien como product manager con otros equipos. Primero, saca a la luz los temas complicados sin ser difícil de tratar. Pon sobre la mesa los asuntos importantes sin hacerte el protagonista. Y por último, tu trabajo es lograr que se tomen las decisiones, no tomarlas todas tú solo.
context: Vikrama is describing the third W - 'your operating model' - which focuses on how PMs collaborate with stakeholders. Due to the 'mini CEO' mythology around product management, many PMs struggle with interpersonal dynamics. He provides three core principles for effective collaboration that help PMs avoid common pitfalls like being seen as difficult or self-important while still driving progress and decision-making.
vocabulary_highlights: raise difficult issues, drawing importance to yourself, in charge of getting the decisions made
topics: Product Management, Leadership & Management, Communication Skills

speaker: Vikrama Dhiman
text: The first thing is whether you are focusing on things you control or whether you're focusing on things that are beyond your control. Second, what's your relationship with change? And third is how you see yourself. The third is very, very powerful and we'll talk about that as well.
text_ko: 첫째는 여러분이 통제할 수 있는 것에 집중하고 있는지, 통제할 수 없는 것에 신경 쓰고 있는지예요. 둘째는 변화와 어떤 관계를 맺고 있는지예요. 셋째는 자신을 어떻게 바라보는지예요. 이 셋째가 정말, 정말 강력해요. 그 부분도 이야기해볼게요.
text_zh: 第一点就是，你到底是把精力放在自己能掌控的事情上，还是老想着那些你根本管不了的事儿。第二点，你怎么看待变化这件事？第三点是你怎么看自己。这第三点特别关键，咱们待会儿也会聊到。
text_es: Lo primero es si te estás enfocando en las cosas que puedes controlar o si te estás enfocando en cosas que están fuera de tu control. Lo segundo, ¿cuál es tu relación con el cambio? Y lo tercero es cómo te ves a ti mismo. Este tercer punto es súper poderoso y también vamos a hablar de eso.
context: Lenny asks what most impedes people's career growth and what causes PMs to shoot themselves in the foot. Vikrama identifies three critical mindset shifts that can either accelerate or hinder career advancement. He emphasizes that while growth frameworks and rubrics are helpful, these underlying mental patterns often determine whether someone actually progresses in their career, with self-perception being particularly influential.
vocabulary_highlights: shoot themselves in the foot, relationship with change
topics: Career Development, Learning & Growth, Decision Making

speaker: Vikrama Dhiman
text: I see a lot of product managers, that's included me at some stage, doing these things, people will come back and say, 'Oh, I am a very high agency PM' or, 'I'm a very collaborative PM.' Earlier on, I used to think that okay, I need to give this kind of work to these product managers. But then I started understanding these things are not just signaling, they are also anti-signaling. They are like, 'Oh, I'm high agency. So it's sometimes okay if I'm little brash, if I cut corners somewhere, if I sometimes come across as a little rude to some people' and so on, right?
text_ko: 많은 프로덕트 매니저(product managers, PM)들이—저도 한때 그랬지만—이런 식으로 행동하는 걸 자주 봐요. 사람들은 "나는 되게 하이 에이전시(high agency)인 PM이에요" 혹은 "나는 협업형(collaborative) PM이에요"라고 말하죠. 초반에는 "아, 이런 종류의 일은 이런 타입의 PM들에게 맡겨야겠다"라고 생각했어요. 그런데 나중에 보니 이게 단순한 시그널링(signaling)만이 아니라 안티-시그널링(anti-signaling)이기도 하다는 걸 알게 됐어요. 즉 "내가 하이 에이전시니까"라며 가끔 거칠게 굴거나, 어딘가를 대충 넘어가거나, 어떤 사람들한테는 좀 무례하게 보여도 괜찮다고 스스로 정당화하는 면이 있다는 거예요.
text_zh: 我发现很多产品经理，包括我自己以前也是这样，老是爱给自己贴标签，会说"哎呀我是那种很有主动性(high agency)的PM"，或者"我是很善于合作(collaborative)的PM"。一开始我还真信了，觉得好啊，那就把这种活儿给这些产品经理做。但后来我才明白，这些话不光是在给自己加分，其实也在暴露问题。就像那些说自己很有主动性的，潜台词可能是"我很有主动性嘛，所以有时候态度冲一点也没事儿，偷个懒走个捷径也行，对人粗鲁一点也能理解"，你懂我意思吧？
text_es: He visto a muchos product managers, yo incluido en algún momento, haciendo estas cosas. La gente viene y te dice: "Ay, es que soy un PM muy proactivo" o "Soy un PM muy colaborativo". Antes yo pensaba que bueno, necesito darle este tipo de trabajo a estos product managers. Pero después empecé a entender que estas cosas no son solo señales, también son anti-señales. Es como decir: "Soy muy proactivo, entonces a veces está bien si soy un poco brusco, si tomo atajos por aquí y por allá, si a veces me ven medio grosero con algunas personas", ¿no?
context: Vikrama is explaining the third career impediment - 'how you see yourself.' He describes how PMs often adopt limiting self-narratives that become career obstacles. When PMs label themselves with specific traits like being 'high agency' or 'collaborative,' these labels can inadvertently excuse problematic behaviors. These self-stories become anti-signaling - while meant to highlight strengths, they actually justify weaknesses and prevent growth.
vocabulary_highlights: anti-signaling, cut corners, come across as
topics: Career Development, Learning & Growth, Leadership & Management

speaker: Wes Kao
speaker_expertise: Community Building, Career Development, Leadership Development
text: I think the blast radius of a poorly written memo is way bigger than most people think. If you are just shooting off a message in a Slack channel with 15 other people, and it's confusing, you didn't include information you should have included, there's going to be a bunch of back and forth. Whereas if you had just taken another look at it, those 15 people would be off to the races.
text_ko: 부실하게 쓴 메모의 파급 반경(blast radius)은 대부분 사람들이 생각하는 것보다 훨씬 커요. 슬랙 채널(Slack channel)에서 15명 정도 있는 곳에 그냥 메시지를 툭 던졌는데 내용이 애매하거나 들어가야 할 정보를 빼먹었다면 확인이나 질문이 계속 오가게 돼요. 반면 한 번만 더 검토했더라면 그 15명은 바로 다음 단계로 넘어갔을 거예요.
text_zh: 我觉得一份写得烂的备忘录(memo)造成的影响比大多数人想象的要大得多。如果你在一个有15个人的Slack频道里随便发个消息，写得乱七八糟的，该说的信息也没说清楚，那就会引起一大堆来回扯皮。但如果你当初多检查一遍，那15个人早就开始干活了。
text_es: Creo que el impacto de un memo mal redactado es mucho mayor de lo que la gente piensa. Si mandas un mensaje rápido en un canal de Slack con otras 15 personas, y está confuso, no incluiste información que debías haber puesto, va a haber un montón de idas y vueltas. Mientras que si le hubieras echado otro vistazo, esas 15 personas ya estarían trabajando a toda máquina.
context: Lenny emphasizes the importance of reviewing your own writing before sending it, noting that many people skip this step due to time constraints. Wes explains why taking time to review written communication is crucial for workplace efficiency. She argues that poorly written messages create much more downstream work and confusion than people realize, affecting multiple team members who must then engage in clarifying conversations.
vocabulary_highlights: blast radius, shooting off, off to the races

speaker: Wes Kao
speaker_expertise: Community Building, Career Development, Leadership Development
text: MOO stands for Most Obvious Objection. A lot of times we're surprised by the questions that we get especially in meetings, we feel blindsided. When really, if you thought for even two minutes about what are obvious objections that I'm likely to get, you often immediately come up with what some of those things are. Are you going to be able to anticipate every single objection? No. But can you anticipate the obvious ones? Absolutely.
text_ko: MOO는 '가장 명백한 반대(Most Obvious Objection)'의 약자예요. 회의에서 특히 예상치 못한 질문을 받아 깜짝 놀라 당황할 때가 많죠. 그런데 사실 단 2분만이라도 내가 받을 만한 명백한 반대 의견들을 생각해 보면 금방 몇 가지가 떠오르는 경우가 많아요. 모든 이의를 다 예측할 수 있냐고요? 아니에요. 하지만 분명히 예상 가능한 건 충분히 대비할 수 있어요.
text_zh: MOO就是Most Obvious Objection的缩写，也就是最明显的反对意见。我们在开会的时候经常会被一些问题搞得措手不及，觉得很意外。但其实你要是花两分钟想想，我可能会遇到哪些明显的反对意见，往往马上就能想出来。你能预料到所有的反对意见吗？当然不可能。但是那些明显的，你绝对可以提前想到。
text_es: MOO significa Most Obvious Objection, o sea, la objeción más obvia. Muchas veces nos sorprenden las preguntas que recibimos, sobre todo en las juntas, y nos sentimos como que nos agarraron desprevenidos. Pero la verdad es que si te pones a pensar aunque sea dos minutos en cuáles son las objeciones obvias que seguramente me van a salir, casi siempre se te ocurren varias de una vez. ¿Vas a poder anticipar todas y cada una de las objeciones? No. ¿Pero puedes anticipar las obvias? Por supuesto que sí.
context: Lenny asks Wes about her MOO framework after mentioning it briefly earlier. MOO stands for Most Obvious Objection, which is a preparation technique for presentations and meetings. Wes explains that people often feel caught off guard by questions or pushback in meetings, when they could have anticipated the most common objections with just a few minutes of preparation beforehand.
vocabulary_highlights: feel blindsided, come up with

speaker: Wes Kao
speaker_expertise: Community Building, Career Development, Leadership Development
text: I have a framework called strategy, not self-expression. And so the idea here is that most of the time, by the time we are giving feedback to someone, we have been frustrated for a while. Then I would schedule a one-on-one with a coworker to tell them the feedback and it would inevitably turn into a venting session where I was in the name of sharing the impact of what they did would share all my frustrations.
text_ko: 저는 '전략(strategy), 자기표현(self-expression)이 아니다'라는 프레임워크(framework)를 가지고 있어요. 요지는 대부분의 경우 누군가에게 피드백(feedback)을 줄 때쯤이면 이미 한동안 답답함과 불만이 쌓여 있다는 거예요. 그래서 동료와 일대일(one-on-one) 미팅을 잡아 피드백(feedback)을 전하면, 결국 '그들이 한 행동의 영향(impact)을 알려주겠다'는 명목으로 제가 쌓인 불만을 다 털어놓는 벤팅 세션(venting session)이 돼 버리곤 했어요.
text_zh: 我有个框架叫做策略性反馈，而不是情绪发泄。这个思路是什么呢？就是说大部分时候，等我们要给别人反馈的时候，其实心里早就憋了一肚子火了。然后我会约个一对一(one-on-one)，想着要跟同事说说这个反馈，结果到最后肯定变成了吐槽大会，打着"分享你的行为对我造成什么影响"的旗号，把我所有的不爽都倒出来了。
text_es: Tengo un marco de trabajo que llamo estrategia, no autoexpresión. Y la idea es que la mayoría de las veces, cuando ya vamos a darle feedback a alguien, llevamos un rato frustrados. Entonces yo programaba una reunión uno a uno con un compañero para darle el feedback y inevitablemente se convertía en una sesión de desahogo donde yo, con la excusa de compartir el impacto de lo que habían hecho, terminaba soltando todas mis frustraciones.
context: Lenny asks Wes for advice on giving feedback effectively. Wes introduces her 'strategy, not self-expression' framework for constructive feedback. She explains that people often wait until they're very frustrated before giving feedback, which leads to unproductive venting sessions rather than strategic conversations focused on behavior change. The framework emphasizes focusing on motivating the desired outcome rather than expressing all your built-up frustrations.
vocabulary_highlights: inevitably turn into, venting session, in the name of

speaker: Wes Kao
speaker_expertise: Community Building, Career Development, Leadership Development
text: I have a framework called CEDAF. C-E-D-A-F. It's kind of like Cedar, but with an F at the end. The C is comprehension. So have I given this person that I'm delegating to everything that they need to understand what it is that I want them to do. E is excitement. Am I explaining this in a way that is making this as exciting as it could be? D is for de-risk. Am I de-risking any obvious risks from delegating this?
text_ko: CEDAF라는 프레임워크(framework)가 있어요. C-E-D-A-F. Cedar랑 비슷한데 끝에 F가 붙은 거예요. C는 이해(comprehension)이에요. 즉, 내가 위임(delegate)하려는 사람에게 내가 원하는 일이 무엇인지 이해하는 데 필요한 걸 다 줬는지 확인하는 거예요. E는 흥미(excitement)이에요. 이걸 가능한 한 흥미롭게 설명하고 있는지요. D는 리스크 제거(de-risk)이에요. 위임할 때 생길 수 있는 명백한 리스크들을 줄여주고 있는지요.
text_zh: 我有个框架叫CEDAF，C-E-D-A-F，有点像Cedar这个词，但最后加个F。C是理解度(comprehension)，就是说我有没有把这个被委派的人需要知道的所有信息都给到位了，让他们完全明白我要他们干什么。E是兴奋度(excitement)，我在解释的时候有没有把这事儿说得尽可能让人有干劲？D是去风险(de-risk)，就是我有没有把委派过程中那些明显的风险都提前化解掉？
text_es: Tengo un marco de trabajo que se llama CEDAF. C-E-D-A-F. Es como si dijeras "Cedar" en inglés, pero con una F al final. La C es de comprensión. O sea, ¿le he dado a la persona a la que le estoy delegando todo lo que necesita para entender qué es lo que quiero que haga? La E es de emoción. ¿Estoy explicando esto de una manera que lo haga tan emocionante como podría ser? La D es para eliminar riesgos (de-risk). ¿Estoy eliminando cualquier riesgo obvio de delegar esto?
context: Lenny asks Wes about her advice for delegating effectively while maintaining high standards. Wes introduces her CEDAF framework for delegation, which provides a systematic approach to assigning work to others. She explains the first three components: ensuring the person understands what they need to do (comprehension), making the work engaging by explaining its importance (excitement), and identifying potential problems upfront (de-risk).
vocabulary_highlights: de-risk, de-risking

speaker: Wes Kao
speaker_expertise: Community Building, Career Development, Leadership Development
text: One of the most common myths about managing up that I definitely felt early on in my career was that I would have to manage up if I were more junior, but eventually I would outgrow it, that I would get senior enough that I would no longer have to do it. And it was a rude awakening that no matter how senior I got, managing up, I not only had to manage up, it actually became more important.
text_ko: 커리어 초반에 제가 분명히 느꼈던 상사 관리(managing up)에 대한 가장 흔한 오해 중 하나는, 주니어일 때만 상사 관리를 해야 하고 결국 시니어가 되면 더는 그걸 안 해도 될 거라는 생각이었어요. 그런데 막상 시니어가 돼도 상사 관리는 계속해야 하는 일이었고, 오히려 더 중요해졌다는 뼈저린 깨달음을 얻었어요.
text_zh: 我刚入职场的时候特别相信一个关于向上管理(managing up)的错误想法，就是觉得只有junior的时候才需要向上管理，等我做到高级别了，就不用再搞这套了。结果现实给了我当头一棒——不管我升到多高的位置，向上管理不但还得做，而且变得更加重要了。
text_es: Uno de los mitos más comunes sobre el "managing up" que definitivamente yo sentí al principio de mi carrera era que tendría que hacerlo siendo más junior, pero que eventualmente lo superaría, que llegaría a ser lo suficientemente senior como para ya no tener que hacerlo. Y fue una revelación dura darme cuenta de que sin importar qué tan senior me volviera, no solo tenía que seguir haciendo "managing up", sino que en realidad se volvía más importante.
context: Lenny asks why managing up is important and why people might underappreciate this skill. Wes dispels a common misconception about managing up - that it's only necessary for junior employees. She explains that she initially believed she would eventually become senior enough to not need this skill, but discovered the opposite was true. Managing up becomes increasingly important as you advance in your career because senior roles involve more ambiguity and strategic decision-making.
vocabulary_highlights: rude awakening, outgrow it

speaker: Wes Kao
speaker_expertise: Community Building, Career Development, Leadership Development
text: I find that people tend to naturally be on the spectrum a little bit too confident as a baseline or not confident enough. So people who are too confident might state hypotheses as if they are fact. So I'm a big proponent of speaking accurately. You can avoid a lot of problems if you speak accurately about your level of conviction and about the actual amount of evidence that you have for something.
text_ko: 사람들은 보통 기본적으로 약간 과하게 자신감이 있거나, 반대로 자신감이 부족한 쪽으로 치우치는 경향이 있어요. 너무 자신감 있는 사람들은 가설을 마치 사실인 양 말해버리기도 해요. 그래서 저는 말을 정확하게 하는 걸 강력히 권해요. 자신의 확신 수준(level of conviction)과 그것을 뒷받침하는 실제 증거의 양(amount of evidence)을 솔직하고 정확하게 표현하면 많은 문제를 피할 수 있어요.
text_zh: 我发现大家天生都有点偏向两个极端——要么就是太自信了，要么就是信心不足。那些过于自信的人经常把假设当成事实来说。所以我特别推崇准确表达这件事。如果你能准确地说出自己有多大把握，以及你手头到底有多少证据支撑，就能避免很多麻烦。
text_es: Me he dado cuenta de que la gente por lo general tiende a estar en uno de dos extremos: o se sienten demasiado seguros de sí mismos por defecto, o no tienen suficiente confianza. Los que son demasiado confiados suelen presentar hipótesis como si fueran hechos comprobados. Por eso soy un gran defensor de hablar con precisión. Puedes evitarte muchos problemas si hablas con claridad sobre qué tan convencido estás realmente de algo y sobre la cantidad real de evidencia que tienes para respaldarlo.
context: Lenny asks about finding the right level of confidence when presenting ideas or recommendations to leaders. Wes explains that people typically fall into two camps: being overconfident or underconfident in their communication. She emphasizes the importance of 'speaking accurately' - being precise about your level of certainty and the evidence supporting your statements rather than presenting hunches as established facts or being overly self-deprecating about solid recommendations.
vocabulary_highlights: level of conviction, big proponent of

speaker: Wes Kao
speaker_expertise: Community Building, Career Development, Leadership Development
text: I think that most people assume that their boss has to manage them and they feel a little bit resentful that, why should I manage my boss? They're getting paid more. They are my manager. They have more responsibility. And you can continue to think that way and your career might be fine, but if you embrace that if you manage your boss, they're going to appreciate you much more, you're going to get more opportunities, you're going to have more trust with them, there's all these great things that happen when you decide to manage up.
text_ko: 대부분 사람들은 자신의 상사가 자신을 관리해야 한다고 생각해요. 그래서 '왜 내가 상사를 관리해야 하지?'라며 약간 불만을 느껴요. 상사는 월급도 더 받고, 내 상사고, 책임도 더 많으니까요. 그렇게 계속 생각해도 커리어가 괜찮게 갈 수도 있어요. 그런데 상사를 관리(manage up)하는 태도를 받아들이면 상사가 훨씬 더 고마워하고, 기회도 더 많이 생기고, 신뢰도 더 쌓여요. 상사를 능동적으로 관리하기로 마음먹으면 좋은 일들이 정말 많이 일어나요.
text_zh: 我觉得大部分人都认为应该是老板来管理他们，然后就有点不服气，凭什么要我去管理我老板啊？他们工资比我高，他们是我的上司，责任也比我大。你可以一直这么想，职业发展可能也还行，但是如果你能接受这个观点——主动管理你的老板，他们会更欣赏你，你会得到更多机会，和他们的信任关系也会更好。当你决定向上管理(manage up)的时候，会有很多好处。
text_es: Creo que la mayoría de la gente asume que su jefe tiene que gestionarlos a ellos y se sienten un poco resentidos pensando "¿por qué debería yo gestionar a mi jefe? A él le pagan más. Es mi manager. Tiene más responsabilidad." Y puedes seguir pensando así y tu carrera tal vez esté bien, pero si abrazas la idea de que si gestionas a tu jefe, te va a valorar mucho más, vas a conseguir más oportunidades, vas a tener más confianza con él, hay un montón de cosas buenas que pasan cuando decides hacer "managing up".
context: Lenny asks Wes why managing up is important and why people aren't doing it well. Wes explains that many people feel resistant to managing their boss because they think it's their manager's job to manage them, not the other way around. She argues that this mindset limits career growth and that those who embrace managing up will see significant benefits in their professional relationships and opportunities.
vocabulary_highlights: feel a little bit resentful, embrace that, manage up, decide to manage up

speaker: Wes Kao
speaker_expertise: Community Building, Career Development, Leadership Development
text: The idea behind what I call the state change method is that you should punctuate your monologues with state changes. So state changes are anything that shakes your audience awake and adds some variety. So it might be asking people to put something in the chat box. It might be switching from gallery view where you see everyone in that Brady Bunch grid and switch over to screen share, to share something and then switch back.
text_ko: 제가 '상태 변화 방법(state change method)'이라고 부르는 거의 핵심은, 혼자서 계속 말할 때 중간중간에 상태 변화를 넣으라는 거예요. 상태 변화(state change)란 청중의 집중을 깨우고 분위기에 변화를 주는 모든 행동을 말해요. 예를 들어 채팅창에 답을 입력해 달라고 요청하는 거나, 브래디 번치(Brady Bunch)처럼 모두가 보이는 갤러리 보기(gallery view)에서 화면 공유(screen share)로 전환해 뭔가를 보여준 뒤 다시 돌아오는 식일 수 있어요.
text_zh: 我说的这个状态切换法(state change method)，核心思想就是你在讲话的时候要不断地变换节奏。状态切换就是任何能让听众打起精神、增加点变化的东西。比如说让大家在聊天框里输入点什么，或者从画廊视图(gallery view)——就是那种能看到所有人的九宫格界面——切换到屏幕共享，展示点内容，然后再切回来。
text_es: La idea detrás de lo que yo llamo el método de cambio de estado es que tienes que interrumpir tus monólogos con cambios de estado. Los cambios de estado son cualquier cosa que despierte a tu audiencia y añada variedad. Puede ser pedirles que escriban algo en el chat. Puede ser cambiar de la vista de galería donde ves a todos en esa cuadrícula estilo Brady Bunch y pasar a compartir pantalla para mostrar algo, y luego regresar.
context: Lenny asks Wes about her concept of creating state change in presentations and meetings. Wes explains that most Zoom meetings involve one person talking while everyone else listens silently, which is draining for participants. The state change method involves breaking up monologues with interactive elements to keep the audience engaged and prevent them from zoning out during virtual presentations.
vocabulary_highlights: punctuate your monologues, shakes your audience awake, Brady Bunch grid

speaker: Wes Kao
speaker_expertise: Community Building, Career Development, Leadership Development
text: So the idea behind what I call eyes lighting up is that when you're talking to someone and you're explaining something, you're teaching them, you're sharing your startup idea or whatever the normal response is people will want to be polite. So they'll nod and they'll say, 'Oh, okay, that's interesting.' But there's usually a moment in the conversation where their eyes light up because they are genuinely actually interested in what you are saying at that moment.
text_ko: 제가 '눈이 반짝이는 순간(eyes lighting up)'이라고 부르는 건, 누군가랑 얘기하면서 뭔가를 설명하거나 가르치거나 스타트업 아이디어를 공유할 때의 상황을 말해요. 대부분 사람들은 예의상 고개를 끄덕이며 "아, 그래요, 흥미롭네요"라고 하죠. 그런데 대화 중에 한순간 상대방의 눈이 확 반짝이는 때가 있어요. 그때는 진짜로 그 순간에 당신이 하는 말에 관심을 갖고 있는 거예요.
text_zh: 我说的"眼睛发光"是这个意思：你跟别人聊天的时候，解释什么东西，教他们，或者分享你的创业想法啥的，一般人都会比较客气，会点点头说"哦，好的，挺有意思的"。但通常聊着聊着会有那么一个瞬间，他们的眼睛突然就亮了，因为那一刻他们是真的对你说的东西感兴趣了。
text_es: Entonces la idea detrás de lo que yo llamo "que se les iluminen los ojos" es que cuando estás hablando con alguien y le estás explicando algo, le estás enseñando, le estás compartiendo tu idea de startup o lo que sea, la respuesta normal es que la gente quiere ser educada. Entonces van a asentir con la cabeza y van a decir "Ah, sí, qué interesante." Pero normalmente hay un momento en la conversación donde se les iluminan los ojos porque realmente están genuinamente interesados en lo que les estás diciendo en ese momento.
context: Lenny asks about Wes's concept called 'eyes lighting up' in relation to state changes in meetings. Wes explains that when presenting or explaining ideas to people, most listeners will be polite and give generic positive responses. However, there are specific moments when someone becomes genuinely engaged - when their eyes literally light up with interest. This physical reaction provides valuable data about what content truly resonates with your audience.
vocabulary_highlights: eyes lighting up, genuinely actually interested, at that moment

speaker: Wes Kao
speaker_expertise: Community Building, Career Development, Leadership Development
text: And ironically, the most senior people are best at managing up. This is why they got promoted in the first place because they were great at managing up to their bosses to understand what was worrying their bosses, what was keeping them up at night so that they could take that off their plate. They're great at keeping their bosses in the loop on what's happening so their bosses, aren't constantly having to ask and pepper them with questions every day.
text_ko: 아이러니하게도, 직급이 높은 분들이 상사와의 관계 관리(managing up)를 제일 잘해요. 사실 그게 바로 그들이 승진한 이유예요. 상사가 무엇을 걱정하는지, 뭐 때문에 밤에 잠을 못 이루는지 파악해서 그 부담을 덜어주거든요. 또 무슨 일이 진행되고 있는지 상사에게 꾸준히 공유해서 상사들이 매일매일 계속 확인하거나 질문을 던질 필요가 없게 만들어요.
text_zh: 很有意思的是，越是高层的人越会向上管理。他们之所以能升到现在的位置，就是因为特别会向上管理——能摸透老板在担心什么，什么事儿让老板睡不着觉，然后主动帮老板分担。他们特别会让老板及时了解情况，这样老板就不用天天追着问这问那了。
text_es: Y paradójicamente, la gente más senior es la que mejor sabe manejar hacia arriba (managing up). Por eso llegaron a donde están en primer lugar: porque eran excelentes manejando la relación con sus jefes, entendiendo qué los tenía preocupados, qué no los dejaba dormir por las noches, para poder quitarles esa carga de encima. Son expertos en mantener a sus jefes al tanto de lo que está pasando, así sus jefes no tienen que estar preguntando constantemente ni bombardeándolos con preguntas todos los días.
context: Lenny asks why managing up is important and how to do it effectively. Wes addresses the misconception that senior people don't need to manage up anymore once they reach director or VP level. She explains that actually the opposite is true - the most successful senior leaders became successful precisely because they mastered the skill of managing up, understanding their bosses' concerns and proactively communicating to reduce their managers' workload.
vocabulary_highlights: what was keeping them up at night, take that off their plate, pepper them with questions

speaker: Wes Kao
speaker_expertise: Community Building, Career Development, Leadership Development
text: And so it went from being a conversation about yes or no, are you a helpful person or are you not, are you a team player or are you not into, hey, how do we make sure that the important right things get done? And so it's great for the person who you're saying no to and it's also great for Alex because whenever we had those conversations, I always thought that he was really thoughtful about making sure that the most important projects that we want to work on stayed prioritized.
text_ko: 그래서 그 대화는 '너는 도움이 되는 사람이냐, 아니냐', '팀 플레이어냐, 아니냐' 같은 예/아니오 식 논쟁에서 '어떻게 하면 정말로 중요하고 올바른 일들이 제대로 끝나게 할까?'로 바뀌었어요. 그 방식은 거절당하는 사람에게도 좋았고 알렉스에게도 좋았어요. 그런 얘기를 나눌 때마다 저는 알렉스가 우리가 하려는 가장 중요한 프로젝트들이 계속 우선순위에 남도록 정말 신중하게 신경 쓴다고 늘 느꼈거든요.
text_zh: 所以这个对话就从原来的"你到底帮不帮忙"、"你是不是团队合作的人"这种非黑即白的问题，变成了"我们怎么确保重要的事情能做好"。这样对被拒绝的人来说挺好的，对Alex来说也挺好，因为每次我们聊这些的时候，我都觉得他真的很用心在确保最重要的项目能保持优先级。
text_es: Y así pasó de ser una conversación sobre sí o no, ¿eres una persona que ayuda o no?, ¿eres alguien que trabaja en equipo o no?, a algo más como: oye, ¿cómo nos aseguramos de que se hagan las cosas importantes y correctas? Y esto es genial tanto para la persona a la que le estás diciendo que no como para Alex, porque cada vez que teníamos esas conversaciones, siempre me parecía que él realmente se tomaba el tiempo de asegurarse de que los proyectos más importantes en los que queríamos trabajar siguieran siendo prioridad.
context: Lenny asks Wes for advice on how to say no effectively, mentioning his own struggles with declining requests politely. Wes shares a technique she learned from her colleague Alex, who would reframe 'no' conversations by discussing trade-offs instead of outright rejection. Rather than making it about whether someone is helpful or cooperative, Alex would explain what work would need to be deprioritized if he took on the new request, making it a strategic prioritization discussion.
vocabulary_highlights: are you a team player or are you not, stayed prioritized

speaker: Wes Kao
speaker_expertise: Community Building, Career Development, Leadership Development
text: A lot of times when we write a sentence, there's actually already a point of view or there's a point of view baked in, but you don't want it to be an accidental point of view. I was just talking to my team member about this, she asked me to give her some feedback on something that she wrote and the way that she had written her paragraph was leading for the reader.
text_ko: 글을 쓸 때 문장 안에 이미 관점(point of view)이 녹아 들어가는 경우가 많은데, 그 관점이 의도치 않게 묻어나오는 건 원치 않아요. 방금 팀원이랑 이 얘기를 했는데, 팀원이 자기 글에 대해 피드백을 부탁했어요. 그런데 그가 쓴 단락(paragraph)의 표현 방식이 읽는 사람을 특정 방향으로 이끄는(leading) 식이었어요.
text_zh: 很多时候我们写一句话的时候，其实已经带了某种观点或者说观点已经融入进去了，但你不希望这个观点是无意中带出来的。我刚才跟我团队成员聊这个事，她让我给她写的东西提点意见，结果她那段话的写法明显在引导读者的想法。
text_es: Muchas veces cuando redactamos algo, ya llevamos un punto de vista incorporado, o sea, ya está ahí metido, pero no queremos que sea un punto de vista accidental. Justo estaba hablando de esto con una compañera de mi equipo - me pidió que le diera feedback sobre algo que había escrito y la forma en que había redactado su párrafo estaba dirigiendo al lector hacia una conclusión.
context: Lenny asks Wes for general writing advice beyond the concepts they've already discussed. Wes emphasizes the importance of studying the technical craft of writing rather than just mimicking social media content. She explains how writers often unconsciously embed a point of view in their sentences, and shares an example of giving feedback to a team member whose writing was inadvertently leading the reader toward a specific conclusion.
vocabulary_highlights: point of view baked in, accidental point of view, leading for the reader

speaker: Will Larson
text: I think that we often treat engineers a little bit like children instead of giving them the responsibilities and ability to actually thrive as adults. And so like, 'Oh, the engineers won't want to do that work.' Well, that's actually not good for the engineers to be sheltered from what is important. And so actually one of the, I think, highlights is that I think we're coming back this moment where we can actually treat engineers like our peers and put them into really senior leadership roles and not have this kind of baseline assumption of like, 'Oh, we have to coddle them or hide them from the real problems.' And this is how they're going to get the opportunity to grow as well.
text_ko: 저는 우리가 엔지니어들(engineers)을 어른으로서 실제로 잘 자랄 수 있게 책임과 권한을 주기보다, 마치 아이처럼 대하는 경우가 종종 있다고 생각해요. '엔지니어들이 그런 일을 하려 하지 않을 거야'라고 말하는 사람들이 있는데, 중요한 일에서 그들을 보호막으로 감싸는 건 오히려 좋지 않아요. 그래서 제가 중요하게 보는 것 중 하나는 지금이 엔지니어들을 동료로 대우해서 진짜로 시니어 리더십 역할(senior leadership roles)에 기용하고, '우리가 그들을 애지중지하거나 실제 문제에서 숨겨줘야 해'라는 기본 가정을 버릴 수 있는 순간으로 돌아오는 것 같다는 점이에요. 그래야 엔지니어들도 성장할 기회를 얻어요.
text_zh: 我觉得我们经常把工程师当小孩一样对待，而不是给他们真正的责任和机会让他们像成年人一样发挥才能。就像，"哦，工程师肯定不愿意干这活儿。" 其实这样把工程师保护起来，不让他们接触重要的事情，对他们反而不好。所以我觉得现在有个很好的趋势，就是我们终于可以把工程师当作真正的同事来看待，让他们担任真正的高级领导职位，而不是默认觉得"哦，我们得哄着他们，不能让他们碰真正的难题。" 这样他们才有机会真正成长起来。
text_es: Creo que muchas veces tratamos a los ingenieros un poco como si fueran niños, en lugar de darles las responsabilidades y la oportunidad de realmente destacar como adultos. Y entonces es como, "Ay, a los ingenieros no les va a gustar hacer ese trabajo." Pero en realidad eso no les conviene a los ingenieros, que los protejan de lo que es importante. Y entonces, de hecho, creo que algo muy destacable es que estamos llegando a un momento donde podemos tratar a los ingenieros como nuestros pares y ponerlos en roles de liderazgo muy senior, sin tener esa suposición básica de "Ay, tenemos que mimarlos o esconderles los problemas reales." Y así es como van a tener la oportunidad de crecer también.
context: Lenny asks about how engineers' leverage within companies has changed from the zero interest rate era to today's market. Will explains that while engineers previously had significant leverage, the current shift is actually creating opportunities for engineers to take on more meaningful responsibilities. He argues that the previous era of coddling engineers to retain them was actually harmful to their professional development, as it prevented them from engaging with important business problems and advancing to senior leadership positions.
vocabulary_highlights: coddle them, hide them from the real problems, baseline assumption

speaker: Will Larson
text: Systems thinking is basically you try to think about stocks and flows. So stocks are things that accumulate and flows are kind of the movement from a stock to another thing. So what's a simple example of a stock? A stock could be the number of fish in a lake. A stock could be the number of people fishing in a lake. And so a flow between those two could be the number of fish in a lake will decrease at some rate based on the number of people fishing in that lake.
text_ko: 시스템 사고(systems thinking)는 기본적으로 스톡(stock, 쌓이는 것)과 플로우(flow, 흐름)을 생각해 보는 거예요. 스톡은 축적되는 것들이고, 플로우는 한 스톡에서 다른 곳으로 이동하는 움직임이에요. 간단한 예를 들면 스톡은 호수에 있는 물고기 수나 그 호수에서 낚시하는 사람 수가 될 수 있어요. 이 둘 사이의 플로우는 예를 들어 호수의 물고기 수가 낚시하는 사람 수에 따라 어떤 비율로 줄어드는 것일 수 있어요.
text_zh: 系统性思维(systems thinking)其实就是你要考虑存量和流量的关系。存量(stocks)就是那些会积累的东西，流量(flows)就是从一个存量流向另一个地方的变化过程。举个简单的例子，什么是存量呢？湖里鱼的数量可以算是存量，在湖边钓鱼的人数也可以算存量。那这两者之间的流量关系就是，湖里的鱼会按照一定的速度减少，这个速度取决于有多少人在那儿钓鱼。
text_es: El pensamiento sistémico básicamente es que trates de pensar en términos de inventarios y flujos (stocks and flows). Los inventarios son cosas que se acumulan y los flujos son como el movimiento de un inventario hacia otra cosa. ¿Cuál sería un ejemplo sencillo de un inventario? Podría ser el número de peces en un lago. Podría ser el número de personas pescando en ese lago. Y entonces el flujo entre esos dos sería que el número de peces en el lago va a disminuir a cierta velocidad dependiendo del número de personas que estén pescando en ese lago.
context: Lenny asks Will to explain what systems thinking actually means in practical terms. Will provides a foundational definition using the concept of stocks and flows - where stocks are things that accumulate over time, and flows represent the movement or changes between different stocks. He uses the analogy of fish in a lake and fishermen to illustrate how these elements interact and influence each other in a system.

speaker: Will Larson
text: The first rule of strategy is that if you write it down, then you can improve it. If it's not written down, it's hard to say if this PM is just not a good PM or if they're trying to apply the strategy that they've misunderstood or if they actually are correctly applying the strategy from the head of product that's just not appropriate to the problems they're working on, how do you debug any of that?
text_ko: 전략의 첫 번째 원칙은 문서로 적어두면 개선할 수 있다는 거예요. 문서화되어 있지 않으면 이 프로덕트 매니저(PM)가 그냥 실력이 부족한 건지, 전략을 잘못 이해해서 엉뚱하게 적용하고 있는 건지, 아니면 프로덕트 책임자(head of product)의 전략을 정확히 따르고 있는데 그 전략 자체가 지금 그들이 다루는 문제에는 적절하지 않은 건지 구분하기가 어렵습니다. 그럼 이걸 어떻게 파악하겠어요?
text_zh: 战略的第一条规则就是，你得把它写下来，这样才能改进。如果没有写下来，你就很难判断这个PM(产品经理)到底是能力不行，还是理解错了策略在瞎搞，或者说他其实理解对了，但产品负责人制定的策略本身就不适合他们要解决的问题。这些你怎么去排查？
text_es: La primera regla de estrategia es que si lo pones por escrito, entonces lo puedes mejorar. Si no está escrito, es difícil saber si este PM simplemente no es un buen PM o si está tratando de aplicar una estrategia que entendió mal, o si en realidad está aplicando correctamente la estrategia del head of product (jefe de producto) que simplemente no es la adecuada para los problemas en los que está trabajando. ¿Cómo vas a debuggear todo eso?
context: Lenny asks about engineering strategy and Will's observation that engineers often lack clear strategy compared to other functions. Will challenges the notion that companies lack strategy, arguing that strategy always exists but is often not written down. He emphasizes that without documentation, it's impossible to diagnose whether problems stem from poor execution, misunderstanding, or inappropriate strategy application.
vocabulary_highlights: debug any of that

speaker: Will Larson
text: The goal of good strategy is not to appease everyone. The goal of good strategy is to dictate how we invest the limited capacities we have or the limited capabilities we have into the problems we care about. And I think both of them were really effective towards that end.
text_ko: 좋은 전략(strategy)의 목표는 모두를 만족시키려는 게 아니에요. 좋은 전략의 목표는 우리가 가진 제한된 자원이나 역량을 우리가 중요하게 생각하는 문제에 어떻게 투자할지 정하는 거예요. 그리고 저는 둘 다 그 목적을 달성하는 데 정말 효과적이었다고 생각해요.
text_zh: 好战略的目标不是让所有人都满意。好战略的目标是要明确我们怎么把有限的资源和能力投入到我们真正关心的问题上。我觉得这两个方面都很有效果。
text_es: El objetivo de una buena estrategia no es quedar bien con todo el mundo. El objetivo de una buena estrategia es decidir cómo vamos a invertir los recursos limitados que tenemos o las capacidades limitadas que tenemos en los problemas que realmente nos importan. Y creo que ambas fueron muy efectivas para lograr eso.
context: Will discusses examples of engineering strategies from Uber (running their own data centers) and Stripe (using a Ruby monolith). He explains that while many engineers disliked these constraints, they were strategically valuable because they focused engineering effort on customer-facing innovation rather than internal tooling diversity. Will emphasizes that effective strategy requires making tough choices about resource allocation.
vocabulary_highlights: appease everyone, dictate how we invest, limited capacities

speaker: Will Larson
text: I feel really strongly that you can write a lot more if you write what you want to write. And so this is one of the reasons I don't write for financial gain and I don't write very much on a schedule, so I've done a few pieces for magazines, et cetera, but I find that actually really draining to be you have a topic, you have to agree on the topic. If a topic starts missing what you want to write about, you can't fix it a lot of the time and you're also on this deadline.
text_ko: 저는 쓰고 싶은 걸 쓰면 훨씬 더 많이 쓸 수 있다고 정말 확신해요. 그래서 돈을 벌려고 글을 쓰지 않고, 정해진 스케줄에 맞춰 많이 쓰지도 않아요. 잡지 같은 데에 몇 편 써본 적은 있지만, 사실 그런 건 되게 소모적이에요. 주제를 정하고 합의해야 하고, 그 주제가 점점 제가 쓰고 싶은 것과 달라지면 대부분 고칠 수가 없어요. 게다가 마감에 쫓기기도 하고요.
text_zh: 我特别坚信一点，写自己真正想写的东西，产出会高很多。所以我从来不为了赚钱而写作，也不会按什么固定计划来写。我确实给杂志写过几篇稿子什么的，但发现那样真的很消耗人——你得有个选题，还得和编辑商量确定选题。如果这个选题偏离了你真正想表达的内容，大多数时候你也没办法调整，而且还得赶截稿时间。
text_es: Estoy súper convencido de que puedes escribir mucho más cuando escribes sobre lo que realmente te gusta. Por eso yo no escribo por dinero y casi nunca escribo con fechas límites. He hecho algunos artículos para revistas y eso, pero la verdad es que me agota un montón cuando tienes que seguir un tema específico, cuando tienes que ponerte de acuerdo sobre el tema. Si el tema se desvía de lo que realmente querías escribir, muchas veces no lo puedes arreglar, y además estás con esa presión del deadline.
context: Lenny asks how Will manages to write so prolifically while working intense full-time jobs. Will explains his philosophy that sustainable writing comes from writing about topics that genuinely energize you, rather than writing for external motivations like money or deadlines. He contrasts this with commissioned writing for magazines, which he finds draining because of the constraints and external pressures involved.
vocabulary_highlights: really draining, starts missing what you want to write about

speaker: Will Larson
text: My biggest advice to both the EMs and the PMs, is before you try to solve the conflict, it's like pushing to ship this feature, pushing to change the approach. Just make sure you actually understand what they care about. There is this idea that you have to make trade-offs and that there are tons of hard trade-offs to be made in the field, but my experience is if you really deeply understand what everyone wants, there's usually a compromised solution that gives everyone exactly what they want.
text_ko: 엔지니어링 매니저(EM)와 프로덕트 매니저(PM)에게 가장 드리고 싶은 조언은요, 갈등을 해결하려 들기 전에—예를 들어 이 기능을 출시(ship)하려고 밀거나 접근 방식을 바꾸자고 밀어붙이기 전에—그들이 진짜로 무엇을 중요하게 생각하는지 먼저 제대로 이해하라는 거예요. 현장에서는 늘 많은 어려운 트레이드오프(trade-offs)가 있다고들 하지만, 제 경험상 모두가 진짜 원하는 걸 깊이 이해하면 보통은 모두에게 딱 맞는 절충안이 나오더라고요.
text_zh: 我给工程经理(EM)和产品经理(PM)最大的建议就是，在你想解决冲突之前——比如急着推某个功能上线，或者急着改变做事方法——你得先真正搞清楚对方在乎什么。大家总觉得做产品就得各种权衡取舍(trade-off)，这个领域有太多艰难的选择要做，但我的经验是，如果你真的深入理解每个人想要什么，通常都能找到一个折中的方案，让所有人都得到他们真正想要的东西。
text_es: Mi mejor consejo tanto para los EMs (engineering managers) como para los PMs (product managers), es que antes de tratar de resolver el conflicto, antes de presionar para lanzar esta función o cambiar el enfoque, asegúrense de que realmente entienden lo que les importa a todos. Existe esta idea de que tienes que hacer concesiones (trade-offs) y que hay un montón de decisiones difíciles que tomar en este campo, pero mi experiencia es que si realmente entiendes a fondo lo que cada uno quiere, por lo general hay una solución intermedia que le da a todos exactamente lo que necesitan.
context: Lenny asks for advice on how product managers can build better relationships with engineering managers. Will identifies two core problems: misaligned incentives and lack of understanding of each other's needs. He emphasizes that before trying to resolve conflicts between EMs and PMs, both parties should invest time in truly understanding what the other person cares about, as this often reveals compromise solutions that satisfy everyone's core needs.
vocabulary_highlights: pushing to ship, compromised solution

speaker: Will Larson
text: Metrics are about educating the people consuming the metrics about the reality of the rich data underneath. They're not about this perfect data set that shows everything starting with something mediocre and the Dora metrics are really helpful for diagnosis, but if you have to, they can also be a good enough starting place to start reporting to your board or your CEO or to the other executives and then you're like, 'Oh, there's all these problems with them.'
text_ko: 지표(metrics)는 지표를 보는 사람들에게 그 밑에 깔린 풍부한 데이터(rich data)의 현실을 알려주는 수단이에요. 완벽하게 모든 걸 보여 주는 이상적인 데이터 세트가 목적이 아니에요. 보통 미흡한 것부터 출발하는 경우가 많은데, DORA 지표(DORA metrics)는 진단(diagnosis)에는 정말 도움이 돼요. 하지만 어쩔 수 없이 이사회(board)나 최고경영자(CEO), 다른 임원(executives)들에게 보고를 시작해야 할 때는 DORA 지표로 시작하는 것도 충분히 괜찮아요. 그러고 나면 '아, 이 지표들에 이런저런 문제가 있구나' 하고 알게 되는 거죠.
text_zh: 指标这个东西，说白了就是帮那些看数据的人理解底层丰富数据的真实情况。它们不是什么完美的数据集，能把所有从平庸开始的东西都展示出来。Dora指标在诊断方面确实很有用，但要是你非得用的话，它们也能作为一个不错的起点，拿去向董事会、CEO或者其他高管汇报。然后你就会发现："哎呀，原来这些指标有这么多问题。"
text_es: Las métricas se tratan de educar a la gente que las consume sobre la realidad de todos los datos ricos que hay por debajo. No se trata de tener ese conjunto de datos perfecto que muestre todo empezando con algo mediocre, y las métricas DORA son súper útiles para hacer diagnósticos, pero si no te queda de otra, también pueden servir como un punto de partida decente para empezar a reportar a tu junta directiva o a tu CEO o a otros ejecutivos, y después te das cuenta de que "Ay, tienen un montón de problemas estas métricas."
context: Lenny asks about measuring engineering productivity and what metrics or tools Will finds useful. Will discusses the challenge engineers face when asked to provide metrics - they can explain why every measure is imperfect, leading to measuring nothing. He advocates for starting with imperfect but measurable metrics like the DORA metrics, then using questions about those metrics as opportunities to educate stakeholders about the complexities of engineering work.
vocabulary_highlights: rich data underneath, good enough starting place

speaker: Yuhki Yamashita
speaker_expertise: Product Strategy, Product Management, User Experience
text: And I think a lot of PMs have grown to realize this, which is, if you ask an engineer about how much time it'll cost to go and build something, and it's something that they came up with or they're advocating for, it's almost always half the time as something that you are asking for, as a PM. And that motivation is so different.
text_ko: 저는 많은 제품 관리자(PM)들이 이걸 깨닫게 된 것 같아요. 즉, 어떤 걸 만들자고 엔지니어(engineer)에게 얼마나 걸리냐고 물어보면, 그 아이디어가 엔지니어 본인이 제안했거나 본인이 밀고 있는 것이라면, PM이 요청했을 때 예상한 시간의 거의 절반밖에 안 걸리는 경우가 대부분이에요. 그리고 그 동기가 완전히 달라요.
text_zh: 我觉得很多PM(产品经理)现在都明白这个道理了，就是说，如果你问工程师做某个功能要花多长时间，要是这个想法是他们自己提出来的或者他们特别支持的，那估出来的时间基本上是你作为PM提需求时的一半。这个积极性真的差太多了。
text_es: Y creo que muchos PMs ya se han dado cuenta de esto: si le preguntas a un ingeniero cuánto tiempo va a tomar desarrollar algo, y es algo que se le ocurrió a él o que está promoviendo, casi siempre te va a decir la mitad del tiempo que si fueras tú, como PM, quien se lo está pidiendo. Y es que la motivación es completamente distinta.
context: Lenny asks about how to balance letting engineers fix bugs they encounter versus maintaining team priorities and roadmaps. Yuhki explains the importance of bottom-up energy where developers notice problems and fix them organically. He shares insights about how engineer motivation dramatically affects project estimates and execution speed.
vocabulary_highlights: came up with, advocating for, half the time

speaker: Yuhki Yamashita
speaker_expertise: Product Strategy, Product Management, User Experience
text: I think one of the most powerful things, especially for startups, is that bottoms up energy, and maybe a developer noticing something is wrong and just going off and fixing it. And for the most part, I try not to get in the way of that because if people are doing that constantly, and everyone the company is trying to make the product better, that is sometimes a way more effective way to improve the quality of experience than this top down of, oh, let's define this quality experience metric and try to change all the things, because you might miss these things.
text_ko: 저는 특히 스타트업에선 그 보텀업(bottoms-up) 에너지가 정말 강력하다고 생각해요. 예를 들어 개발자가 뭔가 잘못됐다고 보고 그냥 가서 고쳐버리는 경우요. 저는 그런 움직임을 대체로 막지 않으려고 해요. 사람들이 계속 그렇게 하고, 회사에 있는 모두가 제품을 더 좋게 만들려고 한다면, 그게 위에서 내려오는 방식(top-down)으로 '자, 경험의 질(quality of experience) 지표(metric)를 정하고 모든 걸 바꿔보자'는 것보다 훨씬 더 효과적일 때가 많거든요. 위에서 정하는 방식으로는 이런 사소한 것들을 놓치기 쉬워요.
text_zh: 我觉得有一个特别厉害的地方，尤其是对创业公司来说，就是那种自下而上(bottoms up)的能量——比如说一个开发人员发现了什么问题，然后就自己跑去把它修好了。大部分时候，我都尽量不去阻止这种事情，因为如果大家都经常这么做，公司里每个人都想着怎么把产品做得更好，这种方式有时候比那种自上而下(top down)的做法要有效得多——你知道，就是那种"咱们先定义一个用户体验质量指标，然后改这改那"的做法，因为用那种方式你可能会漏掉很多东西。
text_es: Creo que una de las cosas más poderosas, sobre todo para las startups, es esa energía que viene de abajo hacia arriba (bottoms up), y que tal vez un desarrollador se dé cuenta de que algo anda mal y simplemente se ponga a arreglarlo. Y la mayoría del tiempo, trato de no meterme en su camino porque si la gente está haciendo eso constantemente, y todos en la empresa están tratando de mejorar el producto, a veces esa es una forma mucho más efectiva de mejorar la calidad de la experiencia que el enfoque de arriba hacia abajo (top down) de "ay, vamos a definir esta métrica de experiencia de calidad y tratemos de cambiar todas las cosas", porque te puedes perder esos detalles.
context: Lenny discusses the tension between engineers wanting to fix bugs they encounter and product managers needing to maintain priorities. Yuhki advocates for allowing organic, bottom-up improvements rather than always enforcing top-down roadmap discipline, especially for startups where this grassroots energy can be more effective than formal quality metrics.
vocabulary_highlights: bottoms up energy, going off and fixing it, get in the way of that, top down

speaker: Yuhki Yamashita
speaker_expertise: Product Strategy, Product Management, User Experience
text: I think the most crazy version of it, maybe, is Dylan's always reading customer feedback. In fact, has reads the most customer feedback of all of us and has been doing that for a decade. And oftentimes, there used to be this thing where he would drop in tweets that he sees into different Slack channels to be like, hey, this seems concerning, or we're getting this feedback.
text_ko: 아마도 그 중에서 가장 극단적인 건 Dylan이 항상 고객 피드백(customer feedback)을 읽고 있다는 점이에요. 사실 우리 중에서 제일 많은 고객 피드백을 읽고 있고, 10년째 그걸 해오고 있어요. 예전에는 그가 본 트윗(tweets)을 여러 슬랙 채널(Slack channels)에 올리면서 “이거 좀 우려돼요”라거나 “이런 피드백이 들어오고 있어요”라고 알려주곤 했어요.
text_zh: 我觉得最疯狂的可能就是Dylan总是在看用户反馈。实际上，他看的用户反馈比我们所有人都多，而且已经坚持了十年了。以前经常有这种情况，他会把看到的推文扔到不同的Slack频道里，然后说"嘿，这个看起来有点问题"，或者"我们收到了这样的反馈"。
text_es: Creo que lo más loco de todo, tal vez, es que Dylan siempre está leyendo los comentarios de los clientes. De hecho, es el que más feedback de clientes lee de todos nosotros y lleva haciéndolo una década. Y muchas veces, antes había esto de que él llegaba y soltaba tweets que veía en diferentes canales de Slack como diciendo, oye, esto parece preocupante, o estamos recibiendo este tipo de comentarios.
context: Lenny asks what sets Figma apart in terms of customer proximity. Yuhki describes Figma's obsessive focus on customer feedback, explaining how CEO Dylan Field personally reads customer feedback daily and shares concerning tweets with the team. This level of founder involvement in customer feedback has been consistent for a decade.
vocabulary_highlights: most crazy version of it, drop in tweets, seems concerning
topics: Product Management, Leadership & Management, Learning & Growth

speaker: Yuhki Yamashita
speaker_expertise: Product Strategy, Product Management, User Experience
text: I often talk about memification, which is this idea that I found this out most at Uber, I feel, where there's certain insights, data insights, research insights that were memmified to the point where someone like Travis or Dara would just cite this insight in the middle of a meeting, and you know that you've really done your job as, maybe, a researcher or a data scientist or product manager if people are able to do that and draw from that in that way.
text_ko: 저는 '밈화(memification)'에 대해 자주 얘기해요. 제 경험상 특히 우버에서 그걸 가장 많이 느꼈는데, 데이터 인사이트나 리서치 인사이트 같은 것들이 밈화돼서 회의 중에 트래비스(Travis)나 다라(Dara) 같은 사람이 그냥 그 인사이트를 꺼내 말하곤 했어요. 사람들이 그렇게 자연스럽게 그걸 끌어다 쓸 수 있다면 리서처(researcher)나 데이터 사이언티스트(data scientist), 프로덕트 매니저(product manager)로서 일을 잘한 거구나 하고 알게 돼요.
text_zh: 我经常提到一个概念叫"模因化"(memification)，这个想法主要是我在Uber的时候发现的。就是说，有些洞察，比如数据洞察啊、研究洞察啊，被"模因化"到什么程度呢？就是像Travis或者Dara这样的人，在开会的时候随口就能引用这些洞察。如果你作为研究员、数据科学家或者产品经理，能让别人这样自然地引用和运用你的成果，那你就真的把活儿干到位了。
text_es: A menudo hablo de la memificación (memification), que es esta idea que descubrí sobre todo en Uber, donde hay ciertos insights, insights de datos, insights de investigación que se memificaron tanto que alguien como Travis o Dara simplemente citaba este insight en medio de una reunión, y sabes que realmente hiciste bien tu trabajo como investigador o científico de datos o product manager si la gente puede hacer eso y recurrir a esa información de esa manera.
context: Lenny asks about specific skills that have contributed most to Yuhki's career success. Yuhki emphasizes storytelling as crucial for product managers, explaining that good stories must drive action. He introduces the concept of 'memification' - making insights so memorable and sticky that executives naturally reference them in meetings.
vocabulary_highlights: memification, memmified to the point, cite this insight, draw from that
topics: Communication Skills, Product Management, Leadership & Management

speaker: Yuhki Yamashita
speaker_expertise: Product Strategy, Product Management, User Experience
text: There's something controversial about this idea that everyone can see what you're doing or that multiple designers can be in the file at the same time. We like to say that one of the first responses we saw to Figma was, if this is the future of design, I'm quitting, right? I'm changing careers. And there's that tension of that narrative tension, but that is signal that you're part of this revolution and you're trying to change something.
text_ko: 다른 사람들이 당신이 뭘 하는지 전부 볼 수 있다거나, 여러 디자이너가 동시에 같은 파일(file) 안에서 작업할 수 있다는 생각은 논란이 있어요. 우리는 피그마(Figma)에 대한 초기 반응 중 하나가 “이게 디자인의 미래라면 난 그만둘래, 진로를 바꿀 거야”였다고 말하곤 해요. 그런 서사에서 오는 긴장감이 분명 있지만, 그 자체가 당신이 이 혁명의 일부이고 뭔가를 바꾸려 하고 있다는 신호예요.
text_zh: 这个想法确实挺有争议的，就是说每个人都能看到你在做什么，或者多个设计师可以同时在一个文件里工作。我们经常说，当初Figma刚出来的时候，有人的第一反应就是，如果这就是设计的未来，那我不干了，对吧？我要转行了。这种冲突和叙事张力其实是个信号，说明你正在参与一场革命，你在试图改变什么东西。
text_es: Hay algo polémico en esta idea de que todos puedan ver lo que estás haciendo o que varios diseñadores puedan estar en el archivo al mismo tiempo. Nos gusta decir que una de las primeras reacciones que vimos hacia Figma fue: "si este es el futuro del diseño, yo renuncio, ¿no? Me cambio de carrera." Y ahí está esa tensión, esa tensión narrativa, pero eso es señal de que eres parte de esta revolución y estás tratando de cambiar algo.
context: Yuhki discusses advice for product-led growth founders about building emotional connection with users. He explains how Figma's controversial approach to collaborative design - allowing multiple designers in the same file simultaneously - created strong reactions that actually signaled they were driving meaningful change in how people work.
vocabulary_highlights: narrative tension, part of this revolution
topics: Product Management, Growth & Marketing, Strategy & Planning

speaker: Yuhki Yamashita
speaker_expertise: Product Strategy, Product Management, User Experience
text: So Chris, our CTO, and I intervened. We created this new channel, private channel called Concerning Tweets, and it just, we're this small group of us that Dylan can drop us in. And these are tweets that aren't going viral, by any means. They're just things that you see is with one like, sometimes zero likes, but he feels there's an essence of truth to them and we make sure that we look at what's going on there and see if there isn't something much bigger that we should be focusing on.
text_ko: 그래서 최고기술책임자(CTO)인 크리스와 제가 나섰어요. 'Concerning Tweets'라는 비공개 채널(private channel)을 새로 만들었고, 소수의 우리끼리 있는 곳이라 딜런이 필요할 때 우리를 여기로 불러올 수 있어요. 여기에 올라오는 트윗들은 결코 바이럴(go viral)되는 것들이 아니에요. 좋아요(likes)가 하나 있거나 때로는 아예 없을 때도 있는데, 딜런은 거기서 어딘가 진실의 기미를 느끼고 우리는 무슨 일이 일어나고 있는지 꼼꼼히 살펴봐서 우리가 더 집중해야 할 훨씬 큰 문제가 있는지 확인해요.
text_zh: 所以我和我们的CTO Chris就出手了。我们建了一个新的私人频道，叫"值得关注的推文(Concerning Tweets)"，就是我们几个人的小群，Dylan可以把东西扔进来。这些推文根本不是什么病毒式传播的，就是那种只有一个赞，有时候零赞的内容，但Dylan觉得里面有些真实的东西，我们会确保去看看那里到底发生了什么，看看是不是有什么更大的事情需要我们关注。
text_es: Entonces Chris, nuestro CTO, y yo decidimos meternos en el asunto. Creamos este nuevo canal, un canal privado que llamamos Tweets Preocupantes, y somos un grupo pequeñito donde Dylan nos puede incluir. Y estos son tweets que para nada se están volviendo virales. Son simplemente cosas que ves con un like, a veces cero likes, pero él siente que tienen algo de verdad y nos aseguramos de revisar qué está pasando ahí para ver si no hay algo mucho más grande en lo que deberíamos estar enfocándonos.
