context: Yuhki continues describing Dylan Field's obsessive customer feedback monitoring. When Dylan's habit of sharing concerning tweets in team channels became disruptive, Yuhki and the CTO created a private 'Concerning Tweets' channel to contain the process while still capturing valuable signals from low-engagement customer feedback.
vocabulary_highlights: intervened, going viral, by any means, essence of truth to them
topics: Product Management, Communication Skills, Learning & Growth

speaker: Yuriy Timen
text: The only thing that's worse than a channel or a tactic that you tried not working. The only thing that's worse now is when you didn't give it the appropriate shot, right? And you prematurely were erroneously concluded that it doesn't work and it's remarkable how often you find that to be the case when I talk to companies, "Oh, YouTube, we tried it. It doesn't work."
text_ko: 채널(channel)이나 전술(tactic)이 안 통하는 것만큼 안 좋은 건 없어요. 그런데 더 안 좋은 건 제대로 기회를 주지 않고 성급하게 '효과 없다'고 잘못 결론 내리는 거예요. 기업들 얘기를 들어보면 그런 경우가 정말 많더라고요. "유튜브요? 해봤는데 안 됐어요" 이렇게요.
text_zh: 有一件事比你试过的渠道或策略不奏效更糟糕。更糟糕的是，你根本没有给它足够的机会，对吧？你过早地就错误地下结论说它不行。我跟很多公司聊的时候，经常发现这种情况，特别常见。"哦，YouTube我们试过了，没用。"
text_es: Lo único que es peor que un canal o una táctica que probaste y no funcionó... lo único que es peor es cuando no le diste la oportunidad que merecía, ¿verdad? Y sacaste conclusiones apresuradas y equivocadas de que no sirve. Y es increíble qué tan seguido me encuentro con eso cuando hablo con empresas: "Ay, YouTube, ya lo probamos. No funciona."
context: Lenny and Yuriy are discussing common failure modes in growth strategy. Yuriy explains a major mistake he sees companies make when testing new growth channels and tactics. He emphasizes that many companies conclude a growth channel doesn't work without giving it a proper chance to succeed, which is actually worse than trying something that legitimately fails after adequate testing.
vocabulary_highlights: give it the appropriate shot, prematurely, erroneously concluded

speaker: Yuriy Timen
text: I hard count my week at about three to three and a half days a week worth of work, which is a personal choice. And within that constraint, I also feel like for me to do my best work and the work that I also enjoy the most and find the most fulfilling four to five companies is probably the max. If I try to go beyond that, the overhead that it creates in terms of the cost of context switching just becomes overwhelming.
text_ko: 저는 제 한 주를 대략 3~3.5일 분량의 일로 딱 제한해 놓고 있어요. 이건 개인적인 선택이에요. 그런 제약 안에서 제가 가장 잘할 수 있고 가장 즐겁고 보람을 느낄 수 있는 회사 수는 많아야 4~5곳인 것 같아요. 그걸 넘기면 문맥 전환(context switching) 비용 때문에 생기는 부담이 너무 커져서 감당이 안 돼요.
text_zh: 我仔细算了算，我一周大概就干三天到三天半的活儿，这是我个人的选择。在这个前提下，我觉得要想把工作做到最好，同时也是我最享受、最有成就感的状态，最多也就能同时管四到五家公司。如果再多的话，那种不断切换工作内容(context switching)带来的负担就太重了，根本受不了。
text_es: Calculando bien, yo trabajo unas tres a tres días y medio por semana, que es una decisión personal mía. Y dentro de esa limitación, también siento que para hacer mi mejor trabajo y el trabajo que más disfruto y me resulta más satisfactorio, cuatro o cinco empresas es probablemente lo máximo. Si trato de ir más allá de eso, la carga administrativa que crea en términos del costo del cambio de contexto (context switching) se vuelve abrumadora.
context: Lenny asks Yuriy about his advising practice and how many companies he works with simultaneously. Yuriy explains his approach to managing his workload as a full-time advisor, describing how he deliberately limits both his working hours and number of clients to maintain quality. He discusses the concept of context switching costs - the mental overhead that comes from juggling too many different projects or clients at once.
vocabulary_highlights: hard count, cost of context switching, overwhelming

speaker: Yuriy Timen
text: If you have really healthy LTVs, and that usually means that you're attracting a proconsumer buyer, so they may be single player, but they're using it for work. And so maybe they're dispensing it or just the perceived value so much higher that they're willing to bear that $120 and $130 a year subscription.
text_ko: 정말 고객 생애 가치(LTV)가 건전하다면, 보통 프로슈머(proconsumer) 고객을 끌어온다는 뜻이에요. 개인 사용자(single player)일 수 있지만 업무용으로 쓰는 경우가 많죠. 그래서 비용 처리(expensing)를 하거나, 단순히 체감 가치가 훨씬 높아서 연간 120~130달러짜리 구독료를 기꺼이 부담해요.
text_zh: 如果你的LTV(客户生命周期价值)真的很健康，那通常说明你吸引到的是专业消费者，他们可能是个人用户，但是用来工作的。所以可能他们会分摊费用，或者就是觉得价值很高，愿意承担每年120、130美元的订阅费用。
text_es: Si tienes LTVs realmente sanos, eso generalmente significa que estás atrayendo a un comprador "proconsumer" (proconsumer), o sea que tal vez sea un usuario individual, pero lo está usando para el trabajo. Entonces puede ser que lo esté distribuyendo o simplemente el valor percibido es mucho más alto y están dispuestos a pagar esa suscripción de $120 o $130 al año.
context: Lenny asks Yuriy about different growth archetypes for consumer startups. Yuriy is explaining companies that can succeed with paid acquisition strategies. He describes 'proconsumer' products - those used by individual consumers but for professional purposes, which typically have higher lifetime values (LTVs) than typical consumer subscriptions. These higher LTVs make paid marketing more viable since companies can afford higher customer acquisition costs.
vocabulary_highlights: proconsumer buyer, single player, bear that subscription

speaker: Yuriy Timen
text: I think it's very difficult to manufacture. You'd only study when... It's very hard to manufacture product network effects if they aren't there from the get go. So Airbnb from your days, obviously marketplace very strong product network effect dynamics. You think of collaboration tools, Airtable, monday.com, Whimsical, whom we both know very strong inherent product network effects, contrast that with a company like Grammarly. It just wasn't there.
text_ko: 그건 인위적으로 만들어내기 굉장히 어렵다고 생각해요. 연구한다고 생기는 게 아니라, 처음부터 없던 프로덕트 네트워크 효과(product network effects)는 나중에 만들어내기 정말 힘들어요. 예를 들어 네가 있을 때의 에어비앤비는 마켓플레이스라서 프로덕트 네트워크 효과가 당연히 아주 강했죠. 협업 툴 쪽을 떠올리면 Airtable, monday.com, Whimsical 같은 서비스들은 우리 둘 다 알다시피 본질적으로 프로덕트 네트워크 효과가 강해요. 반면 Grammarly 같은 회사는 그런 게 그냥 없었어요.
text_zh: 我觉得这个很难人为制造出来。你只有在... 如果一开始就没有产品网络效应(product network effects)的话，后面想人为制造是非常困难的。像你那时候的Airbnb，很明显，marketplace模式天生就有很强的产品网络效应。再比如协作工具，像Airtable、monday.com、Whimsical这些我们都熟悉的公司，它们天生就有很强的产品网络效应，但你对比一下Grammarly这样的公司，它就是没有这种效应。
text_es: Creo que es muy difícil de crear artificialmente. Solo estudiarías cuando... Es súper complicado fabricar efectos de red del producto (product network effects) si no están ahí desde el primer día. Entonces Airbnb, de tu época, obviamente es un marketplace con dinámicas de efectos de red muy fuertes. Si piensas en herramientas de colaboración como Airtable, monday.com, Whimsical, que los dos conocemos, tienen efectos de red inherentes muy potentes. Contrasta eso con una empresa como Grammarly. Simplemente no los tenía.
context: Lenny asks about when companies should invest in virality and referral programs. Yuriy explains that product network effects - where the product becomes more valuable as more people use it - are usually inherent to the product from the beginning and very difficult to add later. He contrasts companies like Airbnb and collaboration tools that naturally have network effects with Grammarly, which is primarily a single-user writing tool where network effects don't naturally exist.
vocabulary_highlights: manufacture product network effects, from the get go, inherent product network effects

speaker: Yuriy Timen
text: I think SEO is pretty specialized skill set. There are some basic principles that always hold like best content wins and don't do shady back linking and make sure that you're on page. SEO is good and your pages are easily crawl, but I feel like everybody knows that. And where the winners are determined are between the lines.
text_ko: 저는 검색엔진최적화(SEO)가 꽤 전문적인 스킬셋이라고 생각해요. '좋은 콘텐츠가 이긴다' 같은 기본 원칙과 수상한 백링크(backlink)를 하지 말라는 것, 그리고 온페이지(on-page) 관리를 확실히 하라는 것들은 항상 유효해요. SEO를 잘하고 페이지가 크롤링(crawl)되기 쉽게 만드는 건 기본 중의 기본이고, 사실 다들 그 정도는 알고 있는 것 같아요. 진짜 승부는 결국 그 행간, 즉 작은 디테일들 사이에서 결정되는 것 같아요.
text_zh: 我觉得SEO是个很专业的技能。有些基本原则永远不会变，比如说好内容为王，别搞那些见不得人的反向链接(back linking)，还有确保你的页面SEO做得到位，让搜索引擎能轻松抓取(crawl)你的页面。不过我感觉这些大家都知道。真正拉开差距的，其实是那些细节上的功夫。
text_es: Creo que el SEO es una habilidad bastante especializada. Hay algunos principios básicos que siempre se mantienen como que el mejor contenido gana, no hacer enlaces sospechosos (shady back linking), y asegurarte de que tu SEO on-page esté bien y que tus páginas sean fáciles de rastrear (crawl). Pero siento que todo el mundo ya sabe eso. Y donde se determinan los ganadores es entre líneas.
context: Lenny asks whether companies should work with SEO agencies or try to do SEO in-house. Yuriy explains that while basic SEO principles are well-known, success in SEO comes from more nuanced, specialized knowledge. He emphasizes that SEO requires staying current with algorithm changes and understanding subtle optimization techniques that differentiate successful companies from those that struggle with organic search.
vocabulary_highlights: shady back linking, easily crawl, between the lines

speaker: Yuriy Timen
text: I think in the short term paid acquisition and just paid media dollars are contracted and we're seeing it already with Metas advertising revenue, Snaps advertising revenue. There's clearly a global contraction happening to paid media budgets. A big part of it is because all of a sudden the definition of efficient acquisition and good payback windows is shifting.
text_ko: 단기적으로는 유료 획득(paid acquisition)과 유료 미디어(paid media) 지출이 벌써 줄어들고 있는 것 같아요. 메타(Meta)나 스냅(Snap)의 광고 수익에서 그 현상이 이미 보이고요. 확실히 전 세계적으로 유료 미디어 예산(paid media budgets)이 축소되고 있어요. 그 큰 이유 중 하나는 갑자기 효율적 획득(efficient acquisition)의 정의와 합리적인 투자 회수 기간(payback windows)에 대한 기준이 바뀌었기 때문이에요.
text_zh: 我觉得短期内付费获客(paid acquisition)和付费媒体(paid media)的预算都在收缩，这个趋势我们已经能从Meta和Snap的广告收入下滑看出来了。全球范围内付费媒体预算明显都在缩紧。很大一个原因是，突然间大家对什么叫高效获客、什么是合理的回本周期，这些标准都在变。
text_es: Creo que a corto plazo la adquisición pagada y el presupuesto de medios pagados se está contrayendo, y ya lo estamos viendo con los ingresos publicitarios de Meta y de Snap. Claramente hay una contracción global en los presupuestos de medios pagados. Gran parte se debe a que de repente está cambiando la definición de lo que es una adquisición eficiente y buenos períodos de retorno de inversión (payback windows).
context: Lenny asks about how paid advertising effectiveness has changed recently due to market conditions and Apple's tracking changes. Yuriy explains that there's currently a global reduction in paid advertising spending, partly due to economic conditions and partly because companies are requiring much shorter payback periods - from 12 months down to 6 months or less. This has created a contraction in the paid media market as companies cut budgets that don't meet these stricter efficiency requirements.
vocabulary_highlights: contracted, global contraction, payback windows

speaker: Zevi Arnovitz
speaker_expertise: Product Management, AI/ML Products, Company Building
text: I have zero technical background, did music in high school ... when Sonnet 3.5 came out. I remember watching a YouTube video building apps using Bolt or Lovable. It basically felt like someone came up to me and said, "You have superpowers now."
text_ko: 저는 기술 배경이 전혀 없고, 고등학교 때 음악을 했어요... Sonnet 3.5가 나왔을 때요. 그때 Bolt나 Lovable을 사용해서 앱 만드는 유튜브 영상을 봤던 기억이 나요. 그 순간 누군가 저한테 "이제 너에게 슈퍼파워가 생겼어."라고 말해준 기분이었어요.
text_zh: 我完全没有技术背景，高中学的是音乐...当Sonnet 3.5发布的时候，我记得看了个YouTube视频，讲怎么用Bolt或者Lovable来开发应用。那感觉就像有人跑过来跟我说："你现在有超能力了。"
text_es: No tengo nada de formación técnica, estudié música en el bachillerato... cuando salió Sonnet 3.5. Me acuerdo de ver un video en YouTube donde construían apps usando Bolt o Lovable. Básicamente fue como si alguien se me hubiera acercado y me dijera: "Ahora tienes súper poderes."
context: Lenny introduces Zevi as a product manager with no technical background who has learned to build significant products using AI tools. Zevi explains his background and the moment he discovered AI-powered coding tools. He describes watching a YouTube video about building apps with AI platforms like Bolt or Lovable, which was a transformative moment that made him realize the potential of these new technologies for non-technical people.
vocabulary_highlights: zero technical background, felt like someone came up to me, you have superpowers now

speaker: Zevi Arnovitz
speaker_expertise: Product Management, AI/ML Products, Company Building
text: If you're non-technical like me, code is terrifying, but AI just makes it so much possible. In the next coming years, I think everyone's going to become a builder. Titles are going to collapse and responsibilities are going to collapse.
text_ko: 저처럼 기술 쪽이 아니면 코드(code)는 정말 무섭게 느껴지는데요, 인공지능(AI)이 그걸 훨씬 가능하게 만들어줘요. 앞으로 몇 년 안에 거의 모든 사람이 빌더(builder)가 될 거라고 생각해요. 직함과 책임의 경계가 무너질 거예요.
text_zh: 像我这样不懂技术的人，一看到代码就头大，但AI让一切都变得可能了。我觉得接下来几年，人人都能成为开发者(builder)。什么职位头衔啊、工作职责划分啊，这些界限都会被打破。
text_es: Si no eres técnico como yo, programar da muchísimo miedo, pero la IA lo hace súper posible. En los próximos años, creo que todo el mundo se va a convertir en creador. Los títulos se van a desdibujar y las responsabilidades también se van a desdibujar.
context: Zevi discusses how AI is transforming the ability for non-technical people to build products. He acknowledges that code can be intimidating for those without technical backgrounds, but explains how AI tools have made building applications accessible to everyone. He predicts a future where traditional job titles and role boundaries will become less relevant as AI enables more people to become builders.
vocabulary_highlights: code is terrifying, makes it so much possible, titles are going to collapse

speaker: Zevi Arnovitz
speaker_expertise: Product Management, AI/ML Products, Company Building
text: It's the best time to be a junior, contrary to what a lot of people are saying, how there's no more junior roles out there. Yeah, that's true, but also when else in history could you get out of school and just build a startup on your own?
text_ko: 많은 사람들이 ‘이제 주니어 포지션(junior roles)이 없다’고들 하지만, 오히려 지금이 주니어로 시작하기에 가장 좋은 시기예요. 물론 그 말이 완전히 틀린 건 아니에요 — 주니어 일자리가 줄어든 건 사실이에요. 그런데 학교를 갓 졸업해서 혼자서 바로 스타트업(startup)을 만들 수 있는 시절이 과거에 있었을까요?
text_zh: 现在其实是做junior最好的时候，虽然很多人都在说现在没有junior的岗位了。确实是这样，但是你想想，历史上还有哪个时候能让你一毕业就自己去创业做startup的？
text_es: Es el mejor momento para ser junior, al contrario de lo que dice mucha gente, que ya no hay puestos junior por ahí. Sí, eso es cierto, pero ¿cuándo más en la historia podrías salir de la universidad y simplemente montar tu propia startup?
context: Lenny mentions the common belief that AI will replace people, but those who are better at using AI will have advantages. Zevi responds with an optimistic perspective about opportunities for junior professionals in the AI era. While acknowledging that traditional junior roles may be scarce, he points out the unprecedented opportunity for recent graduates to build startups independently using AI tools.
vocabulary_highlights: contrary to what a lot of people are saying, get out of school, build a startup on your own

speaker: Zevi Arnovitz
speaker_expertise: Product Management, AI/ML Products, Company Building
text: I created sort of a CTO. So again, I'm not technical. I have been in product for a while, but I know zero stuff about code. So basically what I did was I created a CTO with the custom prompt of it being the complete technical owner of the project.
text_ko: 일종의 최고기술책임자(CTO)를 만들어놓았어요. 다시 말하지만 저는 기술 쪽은 아니에요. 프로덕트 쪽에서 일한 지는 꽤 됐지만 코드(code)는 전혀 몰라요. 그래서 제가 한 건, 그 CTO를 프로젝트의 전적인 기술 책임자(technical owner)로 삼도록 하는 맞춤형 프롬프트(custom prompt)를 만든 거예요.
text_zh: 我搞了一个CTO出来。因为我本身不是技术出身，虽然做产品做了挺久，但对代码这块是完全不懂的。所以我就是用自定义提示词(custom prompt)创建了一个CTO，让它完全负责项目的技术部分。
text_es: Creé como una especie de CTO. O sea, de nuevo, yo no soy técnico para nada. He estado en producto un tiempo, pero de código no tengo ni idea. Entonces básicamente lo que hice fue crear un CTO con un prompt personalizado donde le dije que fuera el dueño técnico completo del proyecto.
context: Zevi explains his workflow for building products using AI tools. He describes creating a virtual CTO using ChatGPT projects to help with technical decisions and planning. This approach helps him overcome the limitation of coding platforms that immediately start writing code without proper planning, which can lead to bugs and technical issues when building complex features like payment systems.
vocabulary_highlights: created sort of a CTO, know zero stuff about code, complete technical owner

speaker: Zevi Arnovitz
speaker_expertise: Product Management, AI/ML Products, Company Building
text: I always think about this where for some reason, the easiest way for me to think about AI is to imagine it as people. And I think ChatGPT would probably be the worst CTO because it's such a people pleaser and it's so sycophantic.
text_ko: 저는 왠지 인공지능(AI)을 사람으로 상상하면 생각이 가장 편해요. 그래서 가끔 이렇게 생각해요: ChatGPT는 아마 최악의 최고기술책임자(CTO)가 될 거예요. 사람들 기분 맞춰주느라 지나치게 아첨적이어서 리더로서 냉정한 판단을 하기엔 별로일 것 같아요.
text_zh: 我一直有个想法，不知道为什么，我觉得理解AI最简单的方法就是把它们想象成人。我觉得ChatGPT要是当CTO的话，绝对是最糟糕的，因为它太爱讨好人了，简直就是个马屁精。
text_es: Siempre pienso en esto donde por alguna razón, la forma más fácil para mí de entender la IA es imaginármela como personas. Y creo que ChatGPT sería probablemente el peor CTO del mundo porque es súper complaciente y demasiado adulador.
context: Zevi shares his mental framework for working with AI tools effectively. He explains why he customized his AI CTO to be less agreeable than standard ChatGPT, which tends to be overly accommodating. He illustrates this with an example where ChatGPT incorrectly agreed with his comparison between two unrelated technologies, demonstrating the importance of setting up AI to challenge ideas rather than simply agreeing.
vocabulary_highlights: people pleaser, so sycophantic, worst CTO

speaker: Zevi Arnovitz
speaker_expertise: Product Management, AI/ML Products, Company Building
text: I would really recommend starting slow with a GPT project, beautiful UI, super simple, then maybe graduate to like a Bolt or a Lovable, and then go to Cursor in light mode, slowly, slowly, gradually ease in until you open a terminal, go full dark mode, go full dev.
text_ko: 지피티 프로젝트(GPT project)는 천천히 시작하는 걸 정말 추천해요. UI는 예쁘고 아주 단순하게 만들고, 그다음에는 볼트(Bolt)나 러버블(Lovable) 정도로 단계적으로 옮기세요. 그리고 커서(Cursor) 라이트 모드로 가면서 서서히 익숙해지다가, 마지막엔 터미널(terminal)을 열고 완전 다크 모드(dark mode), 완전 개발자 모드(dev)로 가면 돼요.
text_zh: 我真心建议做GPT项目(GPT project)要慢慢来，先搞个界面漂亮、功能简单的，然后可以试试Bolt或者Lovable这些，接着再用Cursor的简化模式，一步一步来，慢慢适应，直到你能打开终端、切换到深色模式，变成真正的开发者。
text_es: Te recomiendo mucho empezar despacio con un proyecto de GPT, una interfaz bonita, súper sencilla, y después tal vez pasar a algo como Bolt o Lovable, y luego ir a Cursor en modo claro, poco a poco, de a poquito, ir adaptándose hasta que abras una terminal, te vayas al modo oscuro completo, y te pongas en full dev.
context: Lenny asks about Zevi's progression from ChatGPT projects to advanced coding tools like Cursor. Zevi provides advice for non-technical people who want to start building with AI. He recommends a gradual approach, starting with simple interfaces and slowly progressing to more technical tools, comparing it to exposure therapy for overcoming the fear of code.
vocabulary_highlights: graduate to, gradually ease in, go full dark mode, go full dev

speaker: Zevi Arnovitz
speaker_expertise: Product Management, AI/ML Products, Company Building
text: What I'll do is basically /review. This tells Claude to start reviewing its own code, but what's even cooler is I have Codex as well as Cursor open. I will have each of them review the code.
text_ko: 제가 할 건 기본적으로 /review 명령어(command)를 실행하는 거예요. 이건 Claude에게 자신의 코드를 스스로 리뷰(review)하기 시작하라고 지시하는 건데, 더 멋진 건 Codex와 Cursor도 열어놨다는 점이에요. 각 도구에게 코드 리뷰(code review)를 맡길 거예요.
text_zh: 我要做的基本上就是让它review一下。这样Claude就会开始检查自己的代码，更酷的是我还同时开着Codex和Cursor。我会让它们几个都来检查一遍代码。
text_es: Lo que voy a hacer es básicamente revisar. Esto le dice a Claude que empiece a revisar su propio código, pero lo que está aún más genial es que tengo Codex y también Cursor abiertos. Voy a hacer que cada uno de ellos revise el código.
context: Lenny mentions that the main challenge for non-technical people using AI to write code is reviewing the code that AI has produced. Zevi explains his solution to this problem: he uses multiple AI models to review each other's code. He has created a workflow where Claude reviews its own code, and then he also uses different AI models like Codex to provide additional code reviews, creating a peer review process.
vocabulary_highlights: what's even cooler, have each of them review

speaker: Zoelle Egner
speaker_expertise: Growth Strategy, B2B SaaS, Marketing Strategy
text: I think part of it is also just saying, "We don't have to be hesitant to jump into these problems. It's important to engage with experts in the field, is not to say that tech solutionism is always the answer." And again, this is not super sophisticated technology, but because we were able to go in and talk to the people who are actually affected, get into the system that already existed, and make something really simple, really fast, it actually did have a huge difference and that's really exciting.
text_ko: 제 생각에는 한 부분은 '이런 문제들에 망설이지 않고 뛰어들어도 된다'고 말하는 것도 포함되는 것 같아요. 해당 분야 전문가들과 적극적으로 교류하는 게 중요한데, 그렇다고 해서 기술적 해결주의(tech solutionism)가 항상 정답이라는 뜻은 아니에요. 그리고 다시 말하지만, 우리가 쓴 기술이 엄청 복잡한 건 아니었어요. 대신 실제로 영향을 받는 사람들과 직접 만나고, 이미 존재하던 시스템 안에 들어가서 정말 단순하고 빠르게 뭔가를 만들어 보니까 큰 차이가 났고, 그게 정말 흥미로웠어요.
text_zh: 我觉得很重要的一点就是，我们不用害怕去解决这些问题。当然了，要跟行业专家多交流，但这不是说技术万能论(tech solutionism)就一定对。还有啊，我们用的技术其实也不算多复杂，但关键是我们真的深入进去，跟受影响的人聊，了解现有的体系，然后做出了一个特别简单、特别快的解决方案，结果真的产生了巨大的影响，这让人挺兴奋的。
text_es: Creo que parte de esto también es simplemente decir: "No tenemos que dudar en meternos de lleno a resolver estos problemas. Es importante trabajar con los expertos del sector, pero eso no significa que la tecnología siempre sea la solución mágica." Y otra vez, no estamos hablando de tecnología súper sofisticada, pero como pudimos entrar y hablar directamente con la gente que realmente se ve afectada, meternos en el sistema que ya existía, y crear algo realmente sencillo y rápido, al final sí tuvo un impacto enorme y eso es súper emocionante.
context: Lenny asks Zoelle what she learned from building VaccinateCA, a volunteer organization that helped people find COVID vaccine locations during the pandemic. VaccinateCA was created when vaccine availability was extremely chaotic, with different eligibility rules at every location. Zoelle explains that they built a simple system using phones, Discord, and Airtable to help hundreds of volunteers call vaccine locations and create a comprehensive database. She's sharing lessons about how tech can solve important problems without being overly complex.
vocabulary_highlights: tech solutionism, get into the system, huge difference
topics: Starting a Company, Strategy & Planning, Leadership & Management

speaker: Zoelle Egner
speaker_expertise: Growth Strategy, B2B SaaS, Marketing Strategy
text: I think if you have an authentic mission and people aren't just like, "Oh, sure, okay. You're connecting the world." But really it's some telephony startup. Like, "Okay." If people feel like it's genuinely authentic to what you're building, it can be incredibly meaningful.
text_ko: 제 생각엔 미션이 진짜라면 사람들이 '아, 그래. 세상을 연결한다는 거구나' 하고 겉으로만 수긍하는 수준이 아니어야 해요. 반대로 실은 텔레포니 스타트업(telephony startup) 같은 거라면 사람들도 '음, 알겠어' 하고 그냥 넘어가죠. 사람들이 그 미션이 당신이 실제로 만들고 있는 것과 진심으로 맞닿아 있다고 느끼면, 그건 엄청 의미가 있어요.
text_zh: 我觉得如果你有一个真正的使命感，而不是让人觉得"哦好吧，你们说是要连接世界"，但实际上就是个电话技术的创业公司，这样的话人们会想"得了吧"。如果大家觉得你做的事情确实跟你在构建的东西是一致的、是发自内心的，那这个意义就太大了。
text_es: Creo que si tienes una misión auténtica y la gente no dice simplemente "Ah, sí, claro. Estás conectando el mundo" cuando en realidad es solo una startup de telefonía. Como que "Bueno, está bien." Si la gente siente que realmente es genuino lo que estás construyendo, puede ser increíblemente significativo.
context: Lenny and Zoelle are discussing how having a compelling mission makes it much easier for startups to hire talent. Zoelle had just explained how VaccinateCA attracted hundreds of volunteers because the mission was so clear and meaningful. They're talking about the difference between companies with genuine, impactful missions versus those with generic or manufactured mission statements that don't truly reflect what the company does.
vocabulary_highlights: genuinely authentic, connecting the world, telephony startup

speaker: Zoelle Egner
speaker_expertise: Growth Strategy, B2B SaaS, Marketing Strategy
text: I think I repeated the same three talking points about why what we were doing mattered 5,000 times. Cannot overemphasize how many times I said the same stuff, and so did every other member of the board. It really is important and people will fill in the blanks with totally wild things if you don't continuously have that discipline of repeating yourself.
text_ko: 우리가 하는 일이 왜 중요한지에 대한 같은 세 가지 토킹 포인트(talking points)를 5,000번은 반복한 것 같아요. 제가 같은 얘기를 몇 번이나 했는지 아무리 강조해도 지나치지 않아요. 이사회(board)의 다른 구성원들도 모두 똑같이 반복했어요. 이건 정말 중요한데, 계속해서 반복하는 규율(discipline of repeating yourself)이 없으면 사람들은 빈칸을 완전히 엉뚱한 내용으로 채워 넣더라고요.
text_zh: 我觉得我把为什么我们做的事情很重要这三个要点重复了5000遍。真的不夸张，我说了无数遍同样的话，董事会其他成员也是这样。这真的很关键，如果你不坚持不断地重复，人们就会自己脑补出各种离谱的东西来填空。
text_es: Creo que repetí los mismos tres puntos clave sobre por qué lo que estábamos haciendo era importante como 5,000 veces. No puedo exagerar lo mucho que dije las mismas cosas, y todos los demás miembros de la junta también. De verdad es súper importante y la gente se inventa cosas completamente locas si no tienes esa disciplina de repetirte constantemente.
context: Lenny asks Zoelle about the second lesson she learned from running VaccinateCA. Zoelle is explaining the critical importance of constantly repeating key messages when managing a large, diverse group of volunteers. VaccinateCA had hundreds of volunteers from different backgrounds joining and leaving at different times, making clear communication essential. She's emphasizing how leaders must be willing to repeat the same core messages thousands of times to keep everyone aligned.
vocabulary_highlights: cannot overemphasize, fill in the blanks with totally wild things, discipline of repeating yourself

speaker: Zoelle Egner
speaker_expertise: Growth Strategy, B2B SaaS, Marketing Strategy
text: So if you can be like, "Here are three templates that a person you might be excited about." That can be really helpful. Where people sometimes get confused about templates, or have the wrong expectations about templates, is when they think that templates are going to be an acquisition mechanism, and they don't build in the foundation that is necessary for that to be true.
text_ko: 그래서 '여기 흥미로워하실 만한 템플릿(templates) 세 가지가 있어요'라고 보여줄 수 있으면 정말 도움이 돼요. 사람들이 템플릿에 대해 혼동하거나 잘못된 기대를 가지는 건, 템플릿을 사용자 획득 수단(acquisition mechanism)이라고 생각하면서 그게 효과를 내려면 필요한 기반을 마련하지 않기 때문이에요.
text_zh: 所以你可以这样说："这里有三个模板，可能是你会感兴趣的那种人用的。" 这样会很有帮助。但是大家有时候对模板(template)会有误解，或者期望值不对，就是觉得模板本身就能帮你获客，但其实他们没有先把必要的基础打好，这样肯定不行的。
text_es: Entonces si puedes decir algo como: "Mira, aquí tienes tres plantillas de gente que te podría interesar." Eso puede ser súper útil. Donde la gente a veces se confunde con las plantillas, o tiene expectativas equivocadas sobre ellas, es cuando piensan que las plantillas van a ser un mecanismo de captación (acquisition mechanism), pero no construyen la base que se necesita para que eso realmente funcione.
context: Lenny asks Zoelle about her thoughts on the power and importance of templates for software companies, noting that many companies now create templates because they see how successful they were for Airtable and Notion. Zoelle is explaining that templates can be valuable for helping horizontal products (those that can be used for many different purposes) narrow down the use cases for users, but many companies misunderstand their primary purpose and expect them to drive new customer acquisition.
vocabulary_highlights: acquisition mechanism, build in the foundation, that is necessary for that to be true

speaker: Zoelle Egner
speaker_expertise: Growth Strategy, B2B SaaS, Marketing Strategy
text: What it is good for is credibility. And that's where, if you have really clear goals, and you know how you are ready to leverage the asset of a piece of PR coverage, then it can be helpful to you. So the two goals I always recommend to founders when thinking about using PR, are either hiring or maybe improving the response rate for your cold outbound.
text_ko: 그게 좋은 점은 신뢰도를 쌓아준다는 거예요. 바로 그럴 때, 목표가 정말 명확하고 PR 보도(PR coverage)를 어떻게 활용할지 준비가 돼 있다면 도움이 될 수 있어요. 그래서 제가 창업자들에게 PR을 활용할 때 항상 추천하는 두 가지 목표는 채용(hiring)이나 콜드 아웃바운드(cold outbound)의 응답률(response rate)을 높이는 것이에요.
text_zh: 它的好处主要是能提升可信度。所以如果你的目标很明确，知道怎么利用好一次PR报道带来的价值，那确实会很有帮助。我一般建议创始人做PR的时候，主要考虑两个目标：要么是为了招人，要么是为了提高冷邮件(cold outbound)的回复率。
text_es: Lo que sí te sirve un montón es para credibilidad. Y ahí es donde, si tienes objetivos súper claros y sabes cómo vas a aprovechar el activo de una cobertura de PR, entonces sí te puede servir. Así que los dos objetivos que siempre les recomiendo a los fundadores cuando piensan en usar PR, son o para contratar gente o tal vez para mejorar la tasa de respuesta de tu outreach en frío.
context: Lenny asks Zoelle about her potentially "spicy" take on launches and PR for early-stage startups. Zoelle has just explained that PR is generally not effective for getting leads or users directly, since most people won't click through from articles or remember to search for the company later. She's now explaining what PR is actually useful for and providing specific, measurable ways startups can leverage PR coverage effectively.
vocabulary_highlights: leverage the asset, cold outbound, response rate

speaker: Zoelle Egner
speaker_expertise: Growth Strategy, B2B SaaS, Marketing Strategy
text: Minimally. I'll say, if you care about this, send me a message. I will give you some advice. All of our industry will be better if there are more people working on customer success. So I will help you. Send me a note. Otherwise, I'll try and dig out some other things and maybe you can share them, but there's not a ton.
text_ko: 간단히 말하면, 이 일에 관심 있으시면 저에게 메시지 주세요. 조언해 드릴게요. 고객 성공(customer success) 분야에 더 많은 사람이 참여하면 우리 업계 전체가 더 좋아질 거예요. 그래서 도와드릴게요. 연락 주세요. 아니면 제가 다른 자료들도 좀 찾아볼게요. 그걸 공유해주실 수도 있고요, 다만 많지는 않아요.
text_zh: 很简单。我就这么说吧，如果你真的在意这个事儿，给我发个消息。我会给你一些建议。如果有更多人做客户成功(customer success)这块，咱们整个行业都会更好。所以我会帮你的。给我留个言。要不然的话，我试着再挖掘一些其他的东西，也许你可以分享一下，但说实话也没那么多料。
text_es: Mínimamente. Te voy a decir algo: si esto te interesa de verdad, mándame un mensaje. Te puedo dar algunos consejos. Toda nuestra industria va a mejorar si hay más gente trabajando en éxito del cliente (customer success). Así que te voy a ayudar. Escríbeme. Si no, voy a tratar de buscar algunas otras cosas y a lo mejor las puedes compartir, pero no hay mucho que digamos.
context: Lenny asks Zoelle for resources that founders can use to learn how to invest in customer success early, since she had just recommended that B2B companies hire customer success before sales (which Airtable did). Zoelle explains that while there are many resources for customer success professionals, there aren't enough resources specifically aimed at helping founders understand how to set up and utilize customer success teams effectively.
vocabulary_highlights: dig out some other things, there's not a ton
